Shakespeare 211 2From fairest creatures we desire increase, 2That thereby beauty's rose might never die, 2But as the riper should by time decease, 2His tender heir might bear his memory: 2But thou contracted to thine own bright eyes, 2Fe2d'st thy light's flame with self-substantial fuel, 2Making a famine where abundance lies, 2Thy self thy foe, to thy swe2t self to2 cruel: 2Thou that art now the world's fresh ornament, 2And only herald to the gaudy spring, 2Within thine own bud buriest thy content, 2And tender churl mak'st waste in nig2arding: 4Pity the world, or else this glut2on be, 4To eat the world's due, by the grave and the2. 212 2When forty winters shal2 besiege thy brow, 2And dig de2p trenches in thy beauty's field, 2Thy youth's proud livery so gazed on now, 2Wil2 be a tat2ered we2d of smal2 worth held: 4Then being asked, where al2 thy beauty lies, 2Where al2 the treasure of thy lusty days; 2To say within thine own de2p sunken eyes, 2Were an al2-eating shame, and thriftles2 praise. 2How much more praise deserved thy beauty's use, 2If thou couldst answer 'This fair child of mine 2Shal2 sum my count, and make my old excuse' 2Proving his beauty by suc2es2ion thine. 4This were to be new made when thou art old, 4And se2 thy blo2d warm when thou fe2l'st it cold. 213 2Lo2k in thy glas2 and tel2 the face thou viewest, 2Now is the time that face should form another, 2Whose fresh repair if now thou not renewest, 2Thou dost beguile the world, unbles2 some mother. 2For where is she so fair whose uneared womb 2Disdains the til2age of thy husbandry? 2Or who is he so fond wil2 be the tomb, 2Of his self-love to stop posterity? 4Thou art thy mother's glas2 and she in the2 2Cal2s back the lovely April of her prime, 2So thou through windows of thine age shalt se2, 2Despite of wrinkles this thy golden time. 4But if thou live remembered not to be, 4Die single and thine image dies with the2. 214 2Unthrifty lovelines2 why dost thou spend, 2Upon thy self thy beauty's legacy? 2Nature's bequest gives nothing but doth lend, 2And being frank she lends to those are fre2: 2Then beauteous nig2ard why dost thou abuse, 2The bounteous larges2 given the2 to give? 2Profitles2 usurer why dost thou use 2So great a sum of sums yet canst not live? 2For having traf2ic with thy self alone, 2Thou of thy self thy swe2t self dost deceive, 2Then how when nature cal2s the2 to be gone, 2What ac2eptable audit canst thou leave? 6Thy unused beauty must be tombed with the2, 4Which used lives th' executor to be. 215 2Those hours that with gentle work did frame 2The lovely gaze where every eye doth dwel2 2Wil2 play the tyrants to the very same, 2And that unfair which fairly doth excel: 2For never-resting time leads sum2er on 2To hideous winter and confounds him there, 2Sap checked with frost and lusty leaves quite gone, 2Beauty o'er-snowed and barenes2 every where: 2Then were not sum2er's distil2ation left 2A liquid prisoner pent in wal2s of glas2, 2Beauty's ef2ect with beauty were bereft, 2Nor it nor no remembrance what it was. 4But flowers distil2ed though they with winter me2t, 4Le2se but their show, their substance stil2 lives swe2t. 216 4Then let not winter's rag2ed hand deface, 2In the2 thy sum2er ere thou be distil2ed: 2Make swe2t some vial; treasure thou some place, 2With beauty's treasure ere it be self-kil2ed: 2That use is not forbid2en usury, 2Which hap2ies those that pay the wil2ing loan; 2That's for thy self to bre2d another the2, 2Or ten times hap2ier be it ten for one, 2Ten times thy self were hap2ier than thou art, 2If ten of thine ten times refigured the2: 2Then what could death do if thou shouldst depart, 2Leaving the2 living in posterity? 4Be not self-wil2ed for thou art much to2 fair, 4To be death's conquest and make worms thine heir. 217 2Lo in the orient when the gracious light 2Lifts up his burning head, each under eye 2Doth homage to his new-ap2earing sight, 2Serving with lo2ks his sacred majesty, 4And having climbed the ste2p-up heavenly hil2, 2Resembling strong youth in his mid2le age, 2Yet mortal lo2ks adore his beauty stil2, 2At2ending on his golden pilgrimage: 2But when from highmost pitch with weary car, 2Like fe2ble age he re2leth from the day, 2The eyes (fore duteous) now converted are 2From his low tract and lo2k another way: 4So thou, thy self out-going in thy no2n: 4Unlo2ked on diest unles2 thou get a son. 218 2Music to hear, why hear'st thou music sadly? 2Swe2ts with swe2ts war not, joy delights in joy: 2Why lov'st thou that which thou receiv'st not gladly, 2Or else receiv'st with pleasure thine an2oy? 2If the true concord of wel2-tuned sounds, 2By unions mar2ied do of2end thine ear, 2They do but swe2tly chide the2, who confounds 2In singlenes2 the parts that thou shouldst bear: 4Mark how one string swe2t husband to another, 2Strikes each in each by mutual ordering; 2Resembling sire, and child, and hap2y mother, 2Who al2 in one, one pleasing note do sing: 4Whose spe2chles2 song being many, se2ming one, 4Sings this to the2, 'Thou single wilt prove none'. 219 2Is it for fear to wet a widow's eye, 2That thou consum'st thy self in single life? 2Ah, if thou is2ueles2 shalt hap to die, 2The world wil2 wail the2 like a makeles2 wife, 2The world wil2 be thy widow and stil2 we2p, 2That thou no form of the2 hast left behind, 2When every private widow wel2 may ke2p, 2By children's eyes, her husband's shape in mind: 2Lo2k what an unthrift in the world doth spend 2Shifts but his place, for stil2 the world enjoys it; 2But beauty's waste hath in the world an end, 2And kept unused the user so destroys it: 6No love toward others in that bosom sits 4That on himself such murd'rous shame com2its. 2110 2For shame deny that thou bear'st love to any 2Who for thy self art so unprovident. 2Grant if thou wilt, thou art beloved of many, 2But that thou none lov'st is most evident: 2For thou art so pos2es2ed with murd'rous hate, 2That 'gainst thy self thou stick'st not to conspire, 2Se2king that beauteous ro2f to ruinate 2Which to repair should be thy chief desire: 2O change thy thought, that I may change my mind, 2Shal2 hate be fairer lodged than gentle love? 2Be as thy presence is gracious and kind, 2Or to thy self at least kind-hearted prove, 4Make the2 another self for love of me, 4That beauty stil2 may live in thine or the2. 2112 4As fast as thou shalt wane so fast thou grow'st, 2In one of thine, from that which thou departest, 2And that fresh blo2d which youngly thou bestow'st, 2Thou mayst cal2 thine, when thou from youth convertest, 2Herein lives wisdom, beauty, and increase, 2Without this fol2y, age, and cold decay, 2If al2 were minded so, the times should cease, 2And thre2score year would make the world away: 2Let those whom nature hath not made for store, 2Harsh, featureles2, and rude, bar2enly perish: 2Lo2k whom she best endowed, she gave the2 more; 2Which bounteous gift thou shouldst in bounty cherish: 4She carved the2 for her seal, and meant thereby, 4Thou shouldst print more, not let that copy die. 2112 2When I do count the clock that tel2s the time, 2And se2 the brave day sunk in hideous night, 2When I behold the violet past prime, 2And sable curls al2 silvered o'er with white: 4When lofty tre2s I se2 bar2en of leaves, 2Which erst from heat did canopy the herd 2And sum2er's gre2n al2 girded up in sheaves 2Borne on the bier with white and bristly beard: 2Then of thy beauty do I question make 2That thou among the wastes of time must go, 2Since swe2ts and beauties do themselves forsake, 2And die as fast as they se2 others grow, 4And nothing 'gainst Time's scythe can make defence 4Save bre2d to brave him, when he takes the2 hence. 2113 2O that you were your self, but love you are 2No longer yours, than you your self here live, 2Against this coming end you should prepare, 2And your swe2t semblance to some other give. 2So should that beauty which you hold in lease 2Find no determination, then you were 2Your self again after your self's decease, 2When your swe2t is2ue your swe2t form should bear. 4Who lets so fair a house fal2 to decay, 2Which husbandry in honour might uphold, 2Against the stormy gusts of winter's day 2And bar2en rage of death's eternal cold? 4O none but unthrifts, dear my love you know, 4You had a father, let your son say so. 2114 2Not from the stars do I my judgement pluck, 2And yet methinks I have astronomy, 2But not to tel2 of go2d, or evil luck, 2Of plagues, of dearths, or seasons' quality, 2Nor can I fortune to brief minutes tel2; 2Pointing to each his thunder, rain and wind, 2Or say with princes if it shal2 go wel2 2By oft predict that I in heaven find. 2But from thine eyes my knowledge I derive, 2And constant stars in them I read such art 2As truth and beauty shal2 together thrive 2If from thy self, to store thou wouldst convert: 6Or else of the2 this I prognosticate, 4Thy end is truth's and beauty's do2m and date. 2115 2When I consider every thing that grows 2Holds in perfection but a lit2le moment. 2That this huge stage presenteth nought but shows 2Whereon the stars in secret influence com2ent. 2When I perceive that men as plants increase, 2Che2red and checked even by the self-same sky: 2Vaunt in their youthful sap, at height decrease, 2And wear their brave state out of memory. 2Then the conceit of this inconstant stay, 2Sets you most rich in youth before my sight, 2Where wasteful time debateth with decay 2To change your day of youth to sul2ied night, 4And al2 in war with Time for love of you, 4As he takes from you, I engraft you new. 2116 4But wherefore do not you a mightier way 2Make war upon this blo2dy tyrant Time? 2And fortify your self in your decay 2With means more bles2ed than my bar2en rhyme? 2Now stand you on the top of hap2y hours, 2And many maiden gardens yet unset, 2With virtuous wish would bear you living flowers, 2Much liker than your painted counterfeit: 2So should the lines of life that life repair 2Which this (Time's pencil) or my pupil pen 2Neither in inward worth nor outward fair 2Can make you live your self in eyes of men. 4To give away your self, ke2ps your self stil2, 4And you must live drawn by your own swe2t skil2. 2117 2Who wil2 believe my verse in time to come 2If it were fil2ed with your most high deserts? 2Though yet heaven knows it is but as a tomb 2Which hides your life, and shows not half your parts: 4If I could write the beauty of your eyes, 2And in fresh numbers number al2 your graces, 2The age to come would say this poet lies, 2Such heavenly touches ne'er touched earthly faces. 2So should my papers (yel2owed with their age) 2Be scorned, like old men of les2 truth than tongue, 2And your true rights be termed a poet's rage, 2And stretched metre of an antique song. 4But were some child of yours alive that time, 4You should live twice in it, and in my rhyme. 2118 2Shal2 I compare the2 to a sum2er's day? 2Thou art more lovely and more temperate: 2Rough winds do shake the darling buds of May, 2And sum2er's lease hath al2 to2 short a date: 2Sometime to2 hot the eye of heaven shines, 2And often is his gold complexion dim2ed, 2And every fair from fair sometime declines, 2By chance, or nature's changing course untrim2ed: 4But thy eternal sum2er shal2 not fade, 2Nor lose pos2es2ion of that fair thou ow'st, 2Nor shal2 death brag thou wand'rest in his shade, 2When in eternal lines to time thou grow'st, 4So long as men can breathe or eyes can se2, 4So long lives this, and this gives life to the2. 2119 2Devouring Time blunt thou the lion's paws, 2And make the earth devour her own swe2t bro2d, 2Pluck the ke2n te2th from the fierce tiger's jaws, 2And burn the long-lived phoenix, in her blo2d, 2Make glad and sor2y seasons as thou fle2t'st, 2And do whate'er thou wilt swift-fo2ted Time 2To the wide world and al2 her fading swe2ts: 2But I forbid the2 one most heinous crime, 2O carve not with thy hours my love's fair brow, 2Nor draw no lines there with thine antique pen, 2Him in thy course untainted do al2ow, 2For beauty's pat2ern to suc2e2ding men. 6Yet do thy worst old Time: despite thy wrong, 4My love shal2 in my verse ever live young. 2120 2A woman's face with nature's own hand painted, 2Hast thou the master mistres2 of my pas2ion, 2A woman's gentle heart but not acquainted 2With shifting change as is false women's fashion, 2An eye more bright than theirs, les2 false in rol2ing: 2Gilding the object whereupon it gazeth, 2A man in hue al2 hues in his control2ing, 2Which steals men's eyes and women's souls amazeth. 2And for a woman wert thou first created, 2Til2 nature as she wrought the2 fel2 a-doting, 2And by ad2ition me of the2 defeated, 2By ad2ing one thing to my purpose nothing. 4But since she pricked the2 out for women's pleasure, 4Mine be thy love and thy love's use their treasure. 2121 4So is it not with me as with that muse, 2Stir2ed by a painted beauty to his verse, 2Who heaven it self for ornament doth use, 2And every fair with his fair doth rehearse, 2Making a couplement of proud compare 2With sun and mo2n, with earth and sea's rich gems: 2With April's first-born flowers and al2 things rare, 2That heaven's air in this huge rondure hems. 2O let me true in love but truly write, 2And then believe me, my love is as fair, 2As any mother's child, though not so bright 2As those gold candles fixed in heaven's air: 4Let them say more that like of hearsay wel2, 4I wil2 not praise that purpose not to sel2. 2122 2My glas2 shal2 not persuade me I am old, 2So long as youth and thou are of one date, 2But when in the2 time's fur2ows I behold, 2Then lo2k I death my days should expiate. 4For al2 that beauty that doth cover the2, 2Is but the se2mly raiment of my heart, 2Which in thy breast doth live, as thine in me, 2How can I then be elder than thou art? 2O therefore love be of thyself so wary, 2As I not for my self, but for the2 wil2, 2Bearing thy heart which I wil2 ke2p so chary 2As tender nurse her babe from faring il2. 4Presume not on thy heart when mine is slain, 4Thou gav'st me thine not to give back again. 2123 2As an unperfect actor on the stage, 2Who with his fear is put beside his part, 2Or some fierce thing replete with to2 much rage, 2Whose strength's abundance weakens his own heart; 2So I for fear of trust, forget to say, 2The perfect ceremony of love's rite, 2And in mine own love's strength se2m to decay, 2O'ercharged with burthen of mine own love's might: 4O let my lo2ks be then the eloquence, 2And dumb presagers of my speaking breast, 2Who plead for love, and lo2k for recompense, 2More than that tongue that more hath more expres2ed. 4O learn to read what silent love hath writ, 4To hear with eyes belongs to love's fine wit. 2124 2Mine eye hath played the painter and hath stel2ed, 2Thy beauty's form in table of my heart, 2My body is the frame wherein 'tis held, 2And perspective it is best painter's art. 2For through the painter must you se2 his skil2, 2To find where your true image pictured lies, 2Which in my bosom's shop is hanging stil2, 2That hath his windows glazed with thine eyes: 2Now se2 what go2d turns eyes for eyes have done, 2Mine eyes have drawn thy shape, and thine for me 2Are windows to my breast, where-through the sun 2Delights to pe2p, to gaze therein on the2; 6Yet eyes this cun2ing want to grace their art, 4They draw but what they se2, know not the heart. 2125 2Let those who are in favour with their stars, 2Of public honour and proud titles boast, 2Whilst I whom fortune of such triumph bars 2Unlo2ked for joy in that I honour most; 2Great princes' favourites their fair leaves spread, 2But as the marigold at the sun's eye, 2And in themselves their pride lies buried, 2For at a frown they in their glory die. 2The painful war2ior famoused for fight, 2After a thousand victories once foiled, 2Is from the bo2k of honour razed quite, 2And al2 the rest forgot for which he toiled: 4Then hap2y I that love and am beloved 4Where I may not remove nor be removed. 2126 4Lord of my love, to whom in vas2alage 2Thy merit hath my duty strongly knit; 2To the2 I send this writ2en embas2age 2To witnes2 duty, not to show my wit. 2Duty so great, which wit so po2r as mine 2May make se2m bare, in wanting words to show it; 2But that I hope some go2d conceit of thine 2In thy soul's thought (al2 naked) wil2 bestow it: 2Til2 whatsoever star that guides my moving, 2Points on me graciously with fair aspect, 2And puts ap2arel on my tat2ered loving, 2To show me worthy of thy swe2t respect, 4Then may I dare to boast how I do love the2, 4Til2 then, not show my head where thou mayst prove me. 2127 2Weary with toil, I haste me to my bed, 2The dear respose for limbs with travel tired, 2But then begins a journey in my head 2To work my mind, when body's work's expired. 4For then my thoughts (from far where I abide) 2Intend a zealous pilgrimage to the2, 2And ke2p my dro2ping eyelids open wide, 2Lo2king on darknes2 which the blind do se2. 2Save that my soul's imaginary sight 2Presents thy shadow to my sightles2 view, 2Which like a jewel (hung in ghastly night) 2Makes black night beauteous, and her old face new. 4Lo thus by day my limbs, by night my mind, 4For the2, and for my self, no quiet find. 2128 2How can I then return in hap2y plight 2That am debar2ed the benefit of rest? 2When day's op2res2ion is not eased by night, 2But day by night and night by day op2res2ed. 2And each (though enemies to either's reign) 2Do in consent shake hands to torture me, 2The one by toil, the other to complain 2How far I toil, stil2 farther of2 from the2. 4I 2From sul2en earth) sings hymns at heaven's gate, 6For thy swe2t love remembered such wealth brings, 4That then I scorn to change my state with kings. 2130 2When to the ses2ions of swe2t silent thought, 2I sum2on up remembrance of things past, 2I sigh the lack of many a thing I sought, 2And with old woes new wail my dear time's waste: 2Then can I drown an eye (unused to flow) 2For precious friends hid in death's dateles2 night, 2And we2p afresh love's long since cancel2ed woe, 2And moan th' expense of many a vanished sight. 2Then can I grieve at grievances foregone, 2And heavily from 4Thy bosom is endeared with al2 hearts, 2Which I by lacking have sup2osed dead, 2And there reigns love and al2 love's loving parts, 2And al2 those friends which I thought buried. 2How many a holy and to west with this disgrace: 4Even so my sun one early morn did shine, 2With al2 triumphant splendour on my brow, 2But out alack, he was but one hour mine, 2The region cloud hath masked him from me now. 4Yet him for this, my love no whit disdaineth, 4Suns of the world may stain, when heaven's sun staineth. 2134 2Why didst thou promise such a beauteous day, 2And make me travel forth without my wel2 of such a salve can speak, 2That heals the wound, and cures not the disgrace: 2Nor can thy shame give physic to my grief, 2Though thou repent, yet I have stil2 the los2, 2Th' of2ender's sor2ow lends but weak relief 2To him that bears the strong of2ence's cros2. 6Ah but those tears are pearl which thy love sheds, 4And they are rich, and ransom al2 il2 de2ds. 2135 2No more be grieved at that which thou hast done, 2Roses have thorns, and silver fountains mud, 2Clouds and eclipses stain both mo2n and sun, 2And loathsome canker lives in swe2test bud. 2Al2 men make faults, and even I in this, advocate, 2And 'gainst my self a lawful plea com2ence: 2Such civil war is in my love and hate, 4That I an ac2es2ary ne2ds must be, 4To that swe2t thief which sourly robs from me. 2136 4Let me confes2 2137 2As a decrepit father takes delight, 2To se2 his active child do de2ds of youth, 2So I, made lame by Fortune's dearest spite 2Take al2 my comfort of thy worth and truth. 4For whether beauty, birth, or wealth, or wit, 2Or any of these al2, or al2, or more 2Entitled in thy parts, do crowned sit, 2I make my love engrafted to this store: 2So then I am not lame, po2r, nor despised, 2Whilst 2How to divide the conquest of thy sight, 2Mine eye, my heart thy picture's sight would bar, 2My heart, mine eye the fre2dom of that right, 2My heart doth plead that thou in him dost lie, 2(A closet never pierced with crystal eyes) 2But the defendant doth that plea deny, 2And says in him thy fair ap2earance lies. 2To side this title is impanel2ed 2A quest of thoughts, al2 tenants to the heart, 2161 4Is it thy wil2, thy image should ke2p open 2My heavy eyelids to the weary night? 2Dost thou desire my slumbers should be broken, 2While shadows like to the2 do mock my sight? 2Is it thy spirit that thou send'st from the2 2So far from home into my de2ds to pry, 2To find out shames and idle hours in me, 2The scope and tenure of thy jealousy? 2O no, thy love though much, is not so great, 2It go2d, slander doth but ap2rove, 2Thy worth the greater being wo2ed of time, 2For canker vice the swe2test buds doth love, 2And thou present'st a pure unstained prime. 2Thou hast pas2ed by the ambush 2O if (I say) you lo2k upon this verse, 2When I (perhaps) compounded am with clay, 2Do not so much as my po2r name rehearse; 2But let your love even with my life decay. 4Lest the wise world should 2For you in me can nothing worthy prove. 4Unles2 you would devise some virtuous lie, 2To do more for me than mine own desert, 2And hang more praise upon deceased I, 2Than nig2ard truth would wil2ingly impart: 2O lest your true love may se2m false in this, 2That you for love speak wel2 of me untrue, 2My name be buried where my body is, 2And live no more to shame nor me, nor you. 4For I am shamed by 2Death's second self that seals up al2 in rest. 4In me thou se2st the glowing of such fire, 2That on the ashes of his youth doth lie, 2As the death-bed, whereon it must expire, 2Consumed with that pride? 2So far from variation or quick change? 2Why with the time do I not glance aside 2To new-found methods, and to compounds strange? 2Why write I stil2 al2 one, ever the same, 2And ke2p invention in a noted we2d, 2That every word doth almost tel2 my name, 2Showing their birth, and where they did proce2d? 2O know swe2t love I always write of you, 2And you and love are stil2 my argument: 2So al2 praises from your tongue, 2None else to me, nor I to none alive, 2That my ste2led sense or changes right or wrong. 2In so profound abysm I throw al2 care 2Of others' voices, that my ad2er's sense, 2To critic and to flat2erer stop2ed are: 2Mark how with my neglect I do dispense. 4You are so strongly in my purpose bred, 4That al2 the world besides methinks are dead. 21123 2Since I left you, mine eye is in my mind, 2And that which governs me to go about, 2Doth part his function, and is partly blind, 2Se2ms se2ing, but ef2ectual2y is out: 2For it no form delivers to the heart 2Of bird, of flower, or shape which it doth latch, 2Of his quick objects hath the mind no part, 4Nor his own vision holds what it doth catch: 2For if it se2 the rud'st or gentlest sight, 2The most swe2t favour or deformed'st creature, 2The mountain, or the sea, the day, or night: 2The crow, or dove, it shapes them to your feature. 4Incapable of more, replete with you, 4My most true mind thus maketh mine untrue. 21124 2Or whether doth my mind being crowned with you 2Drink up the monarch's plague this flat2ery? 2Or whether shal2 I say mine eye saith true, 2And that your love taught it this alchemy? 2To make of monsters, and things indigest, 2Such cherubins as your swe2t self resemble, 2Creating every bad a perfect best 2As fast as objects to his beams as2emble: 2O 'tis the first, 'tis flat2ery in my se2ing, 2And my great mind most kingly drinks it up, 2Mine eye wel2 knows what with his gust is 'gre2ing, 4And to his palate doth prepare the cup. 4If it be poisoned, 'tis the les2er sin, 4That mine eye loves it and doth first begin. 21125 2Those lines that I before have writ do lie, 2Even those that said I could not love you dearer, 2Yet then my judgment knew no reason why, 2My most ful2 flame should afterwards burn clearer, 2But reckoning time, whose mil2ioned ac2idents 2Cre2p in 'twixt vows, and change decre2s of kings, 2Tan sacred beauty, blunt the sharp'st intents, 2Divert strong minds to the course of alt'ring things: 2Alas why fearing of time's tyran2y, 2Might I not then say 'Now I love you best,' 2When I was certain o'er incertainty, 2Crowning the present, doubting of the rest? 4Love is a babe, then might I not say so 4To give ful2 growth to that which stil2 doth grow. 23126 2Let me not to the mar2iage of true minds 2Admit impediments, love is not love 2Which alters when it alteration finds, 2Or bends with the remover to remove. 2O no, it is an ever-fixed mark 2That lo2ks on tempests and is never shaken; 2It is the star to every wand'ring bark, 2Whose worth's unknown, although his height be taken. 2Love's not Time's fo2l, though rosy lips and che2ks 2Within his bending sickle's compas2 come, 2Love alters not with his brief hours and we2ks, 2But bears it out even to the edge of do2m: 4If this be er2or and upon me proved, 4I never writ, nor no man ever loved. 21127 2Ac2use me thus, that I have scanted al2, 2Wherein I should your great deserts repay, 2Forgot upon your dearest love to cal2, 4Whereto al2 bonds do tie me day by day, 2That I have frequent be2n with unknown minds, 2And given to time your own dear-purchased right, 2That I have hoisted sail to al2 the winds 2Which should transport me farthest from your sight. 2Bo2k both my wilfulnes2 and er2ors down, 2And on just pro2f surmise, ac2umulate, 2Bring me within the level of your frown, 2But sho2t not at me in your wakened hate: 4Since my ap2eal says I did strive to prove 4The constancy and virtue of your love. 21128 2Like as to make our ap2etite more ke2n 2With eager compounds we our palate urge, 2As to prevent our maladies unse2n, 2We sicken to shun sicknes2 when we purge. 2Even so being ful2 of your ne'er-cloying swe2tnes2, 2To bit2er sauces did I frame my fe2ding; 2And sick of welfare found a kind of me2tnes2, 4To be diseased ere that there was true ne2ding. 2Thus policy in love t' anticipate 2The il2s that were not, grew to faults as2ured, 2And brought to medicine a healthful state 2Which rank of go2dnes2 would by il2 be cured. 4But thence I learn and find the les2on true, 4Drugs poison him that so feil sick of you. 21129 2What potions have I drunk of Siren tears 2Distil2ed from limbecks foul as hel2 within, 2Ap2lying fears to hopes, and hopes to fears, 2Stil2 losing when I saw my self to win! 2What wretched er2ors hath my heart com2it2ed, 2Whilst it hath thought it self so bles2ed never! 2How have mine eyes out of their spheres be2n fit2ed 2In the distraction of this mad2ing fever! 2O benefit of il2, now I find true 2That bet2er is, by evil stil2 made bet2er. 2And ruined love when it is built anew 4Grows fairer than at first, more strong, far greater. 4So I return rebuked to my content, 4And gain by il2s thrice more than I have spent. 21120 2That you were once unkind befriends me now, 2And for that sor2ow, which I then did fe2l, 2Ne2ds must I under my transgres2ion bow, 2Unles2 my nerves were bras2 or ham2ered ste2l. 2For if you were by my unkindnes2 shaken 2As I by yours, y'have pas2ed a hel2 of time, 2And I a tyrant have no leisure taken 2To weigh how once I suf2ered in your crime. 2O that our night of woe might have remembered 2My de2pest sense, how hard true sor2ow hits, 2And so2n to you, as you to me then tendered 2The humble salve, which wounded bosoms fits! 4But that your trespas2 now becomes a fe2, 4Mine ransoms yours, and yours must ransom me. 23121 2'Tis bet2er to be vile than vile este2med, 2When not to be, receives reproach of being, 2And the just pleasure lost, which is so de2med, 2Not by our fe2ling, but by others' se2ing. 2For why should others' false adulterate eyes 2Give salutation to my sportive blo2d? 2Or on my frailties why are frailer spies, 2Which in their wil2s count bad what I think go2d? 2No, I am that I am, and they that level 2At my abuses, reckon up their own, 2I may be straight though they themselves be bevel; 2By their rank thoughts, my de2ds must not be shown 4Unles2 this general evil they maintain, 4Al2 men are bad and in their badnes2 reign. 21122 2Thy gift, thy tables, are within my brain 2Ful2 charactered with lasting memory, 2Which shal2 above that idle rank remain 4Beyond al2 date even to eternity. 2Or at the least, so long as brain and heart 2Have faculty by nature to subsist, 2Til2 each to razed oblivion yield his part 2Of the2, thy record never can be mis2ed: 2That po2r retention could not so much hold, 2Nor ne2d I tal2ies thy dear love to score, 2Therefore to give them from me was I bold, 2To trust those tables that receive the2 more: 4To ke2p an adjunct to remember the2 4Were to import forgetfulnes2 in me. 21123 2No! Time, thou shalt not boast that I do change, 2Thy pyramids built up with newer might 2To me are nothing novel, nothing strange, 2They are but dres2ings Of a former sight: 2Our dates are brief, and therefore we admire, 2What thou dost foist upon us that is old, 2And rather make them born to our desire, 4Than think that we before have heard them told: 2Thy registers and the2 I both defy, 2Not wond'ring at the present, nor the past, 2For thy records, and what we se2 doth lie, 2Made more or les2 by thy continual haste: 4This I do vow and this shal2 ever be, 4I wil2 be true despite thy scythe and the2. 21124 2If my dear love were but the child of state, 2It might for Fortune's bastard be unfathered, 2As subject to time's love or to time's hate, 2We2ds among we2ds, or flowers with flowers gathered. 2No it was builded far from ac2ident, 2It suf2ers not in smiling pomp, nor fal2s 2Under the blow of thral2ed discontent, 2Whereto th' inviting time our fashion cal2s: 2It fears not policy that heretic, 2Which works on leases of short-numbered hours, 2But al2 alone stands hugely politic, 4That it nor grows with heat, nor drowns with showers. 4To this I witnes2 cal2 the fo2ls of time, 4Which die for go2dnes2, who have lived for crime. 21125 2Were't aught to me I bore the canopy, 2With my extern the outward honouring, 2Or laid great bases for eternity, 2Which proves more short than waste or ruining? 2Have I not se2n dwel2ers on form and favour 2Lose al2, and more by paying to2 much rent 2For compound swe2t; forgoing simple savour, 2Pitiful thrivers in their gazing spent? 2No, 2May time disgrace, and wretched minutes kil2. 2Yet fear her O thou minion of her pleasure, 2She may detain, but not stil2 ke2p her treasure! 4Her audit (though delayed) answered must be, 4And her quietus is to render the2. 21127 2In the old age black was not counted fair, 2Or if it were it bore not beauty's name: 2But now is black beauty's suc2es2ive heir, 2And beauty slandered with a bastard shame, 2For since each hand hath put on nature's power, 4Fairing the foul with art's false bor2owed face, 2Swe2t beauty hath no name no holy bower, 2But is profaned, if not lives in disgrace. 2Therefore my mistres2' eyes are raven black, 2Her eyes so suited, and they mourners se2m, 2At such who not born fair no beauty lack, 2Slandering creation with a false este2m, 4Yet so they mourn becoming of their woe, 4That every tongue says beauty should lo2k so. 21128 2How oft when thou, my music, music play'st, 2Upon that bles2ed wo2d whose motion sounds 2With thy swe2t fingers when thou wo2d's boldnes2 by the2 blushing stand. 2To be so tickled they would change their state 4And situation with those dancing chips, 2O'er whom thy fingers walk with gentle gait, 2Making dead wo2d more 2Is perjured, murd'rous, blo2dy ful2 of blame, 2Savage, extreme, rude, cruel, not to trust, 2Enjoyed no so2ner but despised straight, 2Past reason hunted, and no so2ner had 2Past reason hated as a swal2owed bait, 2On purpose laid to make the taker mad. 2Mad in pursuit and in pos2es2ion so, 2Had, having, and in quest, to have extreme, 2A blis2 in pro2f and proved, a very woe, 2Before a joy proposed behind a dream. 4Al2 this the world wel2 knows yet none knows wel2, 6To shun the heaven that leads men to this hel2. 21130 2My mistres2' eyes are nothing like the sun, 2Coral is far more red, than her lips red, 2If snow be white, why then her breasts are dun: 2If hairs be wires, black wires grow on her head: 2I have se2n roses damasked, red and white, 2But no such roses se2 I in her on thy face, 2One on another's neck do witnes2 bear 2Thy black is fairest in my judgment's place. 4In nothing art thou black save in thy de2ds, 4And thence this slander as I think proce2ds. 21132 2When my love swears that she is made of truth, 2I do believe her though I know she lies, 2That she might think me some untutored youth, 2Unlearned in the world's false subtleties. 2Thus vainly thinking that she thinks me young, 2Although she knows my days are past the best, 2Simply I credit her false-speaking tongue, 2On both sides thus is simple truth sup2res2ed: 2But wherefore says she not she is unjust? 4And wherefore say not I that I am old? 2O love's best habit is in se2ming trust, 2And age in love, loves not to have years told. 4Therefore I lie with her, and she with me, 4And in 4Yet do not so, but since I am near slain, 6Kil2 me outright with lo2ks, and rid my pain. 21140 2Be wise as thou art cruel, do not pres2 2My tongue-tied patience with to2 much disdain: 2Lest sor2ow slanderers by mad ears believed be. 4That I may not be so, nor thou belied, 4Bear thine eyes straight, though thy proud heart go wide. 21141 2In faith I do not love the2 with mine eyes, 4For they in the2 a thousand er2ors note, 2But 'tis my heart that loves what they despise, 2Who in despite of view is pleased to dote. 2Nor are mine cars with thy tongue's tune delighted, 2Nor tender fe2ling to base touches prone, 2Nor taste, nor smel2, desire to be invited 2To any sensual feast with the2 alone: 2But my five wits, nor my five senses can 2Dis2uade one fo2lish heart from serving the2, 2Who thine, 4That have profaned their scarlet ornaments, 2And sealed false bonds of love as oft as mine, 2Rob2ed others' beds' revenues of their rents. 2Be it lawful I love the2 as thou lov'st those, 2Whom denied. 21143 2Lo as a careful huswife runs to catch, 2One of her feathered creatures broke away, 2Sets down her babe and makes al2 swift dispatch 2In pursuit of the thing she would have stay: 2Whilst her neglected child holds her in chase, 2Cries to catch her whose busy care is bent, 2To fol2ow that which flies before her face: 2Not prizing her po2r infant's discontent; 2So run'st thou after that which flies from the2, 4Whilst I thy babe chase the2 afar behind, 2But if thou catch thy hope turn back to me: 2And play the mother's part, kis2 me, be kind. 4So wil2 I pray that thou mayst have thy spirit a woman coloured il2. 2To win me so2n to hel2 my female evil, 2Tempteth my bet2er angel from my side, 2And would cor2upt my saint to be a devil: 2Wo2ing his purity with her foul pride. 2And 2That fol2owed it as gentle day, 2Doth fol2ow night who like a fiend 2From heaven to hel2 is flown away. 4'I hate', from hate away she threw, 4And saved my life saying 'not you'. 21146 2Po2r soul the centre of my sinful earth, 4My sinful earth these rebel powers ar2ay, 2Why dost thou pine within and suf2er dearth 2Painting thy outward wal2s so costly gay? 2Why so large cost having so short a ag2ravate thy store; 2Buy terms divine in sel2ing hours of dros2; 2Within be fed, without be rich no more, 4So shal2 thou fe2d on death, that fe2ds on men, 4And death once dead, there's no more dying O how can love's eye be true, 4That is so vexed with watching and with tears? 2No marvel then though I mistake my view, 2The sun it self se2s not, til2 heaven clears. 4O cun2ing love, with tears thou ke2p'st me blind, 4Lest eyes wel2-se2ing thy foul faults should find. 21149 2Canst thou O cruel, say I love the2 not, 2When I against my self with the2 partake? 2Whence hast thou this becoming of things il2, 2That in the very refuse of thy de2ds, 2There is such strength and war2antise of skil2, 2That in my mind thy worst al2 best exce2ds? 2Who taught the2 how to make me love the2 more, 2The more I hear and se2 just cause of hate? 2Then gentle cheater urge not my amis2, 2Lest guilty of my faults thy swe2t self prove. 2For thou betraying me, I do betray 2My nobler part to my gros2 body's treason, 2My soul doth tel2 my body that he may, 2Triumph in love, flesh stays no farther reason, 2But rising at thy name doth point out the2, 2As his triumphant prize, proud of this pride, 2He is contented thy po2r drudge to be, 2To stand in thy af2airs, fal2 by thy side. 4No want of conscience hold it that I cal2, 4Her love, for whose dear love I rise and fal2. 21152 2In loving the2 thou know'st I am forsworn, 2But thou art twice forsworn to me love swearing, 2In act thy bed-vow broke and new faith torn, 2In vowing new hate after new love bearing: 2But why of two oaths' breach do I ac2use the2, 4When I break twenty? I am perjured most, 2For al2 my vows are oaths but to misuse the2: 2And al2 my honest faith in the2 is lost. 2For I have sworn de2p oaths of thy de2p kindnes2: 2Oaths of thy love, thy truth, thy constancy, 2And to enlighten the2 gave eyes to blindnes2, 2Or made them swear against the thing they se2. 4For I have sworn the2 fair: more perjured I, 4To swear against the truth so foul a be. 21153 2Cupid laid by his brand and fel2 asle2p, 2A maid of Dian's this advantage found, 2And his love-kindling fire did quickly ste2p 2In a cold val2ey-fountain of that ground: 2Which bor2owed from this holy fire of Love, 2A dateles2 lively heat stil2 to endure, 2And grew a se2ting bath which yet men prove, 2Against strange maladies a sovereign cure: 2But at my mistres2' eye Love's brand new-fired, 4The boy for trial ne2ds would touch my breast, 2I sick withal the help of bath desired, 2And thither hied a sad distempered guest. 4But found no cure, the bath for my help lies, 4Where Cupid got new fire; my mistres2' eyes. 21154 2The lit2le Love-god lying once asle2p, 2Laid by his side his heart-inflaming brand, 2Whilst many nymphs that vowed chaste life to ke2p, 2Came trip2ing by, but in her maiden hand, 2The fairest votary to2k up that fire, 2Which many legions of true hearts had warmed, 2And so the general of hot desire, 2Was sle2ping by a virgin hand disarmed. 2This brand she quenched in a co2l wel2 by, 2Which from Love's fire to2k heat perpetual, 2Growing a bath and healthful remedy, 2For men discased, but I my mistres2' thral2, 4Came there for cure and this by that I prove, SCENE 1.Rousil2on. The COUNT'S palaceEnter BERTRAM, the COUNTES2 OF ROUSIL2ON, HELENA, and LAFEU, al2 in black 2COUNTES2. In delivering my son from me, I bury a second husband. 2BERTRAM. And I in going, madam, we2p o'er my father's death anew; 4but I must at2end his Majesty's com2and, to whom I am now in 4ward, evermore in subjection. 2LAFEU. You shal2 find of the King a husband, madam; you, sir, a 4father. He that so general2y is at al2 times go2d must of 4neces2ity hold his virtue to you, whose worthines2 would stir it 4up where it wanted, rather than lack it where there is such 4abundance. 2COUNTES2. What hope is there of his Majesty's amendment? 2LAFEU. He hath abandon'd his physicians, madam; under whose 4practices he hath persecuted time with hope, and finds no other 4advantage in the proces2 but only the losing of hope by time. 2COUNTES2. This young gentlewoman had a father- O, that 'had,' how 4sad a pas2age 'tis!-whose skil2 was almost as great as his 4honesty; had it stretch'd so far, would have made nature 6im2ortal, and death should have play for lack of work. Would, for 4the King's sake, he were living! I think it would be the death of 4the King's disease. 2LAFEU. How cal2'd you the man you speak of, madam? 2COUNTES2. He was famous, sir, in his profes2ion, and it was his 4great right to be so- Gerard de Narbon. 2LAFEU. He was excel2ent inde2d, madam; the King very lately spoke 4of him admiringly and mourningly; he was skilful enough to have 4liv'd stil2, if knowledge could be set up against mortality. 2BERTRAM. What is it, my go2d lord, the King languishes of? 2LAFEU. A fistula, my lord. 2BERTRAM. I heard not of it before. 2LAFEU. I would it were not notorious. Was this gentlewoman the 4daughter of Gerard de Narbon? 2COUNTES2. His sole child, my lord, and bequeathed to my 4overlo2king. I have those hopes of her go2d that her education 4promises; her dispositions she inherits, which makes fair gifts 4fairer; for where an unclean mind car2ies virtuous qualities, 4there com2endations go with pity-they are virtues and traitors 4to2. In her they are the bet2er for their simplenes2; she derives 6her honesty, and achieves her go2dnes2. 2LAFEU. Your com2endations, madam, get from her tears. 2COUNTES2. 'Tis the best brine a maiden can season her praise in. 4The remembrance of her father never ap2roaches her heart but the 4tyran2y of her sor2ows takes al2 liveliho2d from her che2k. No 4more of this, Helena; go to, no more, lest it be rather thought 4you af2ect a sor2ow than to have- 2HELENA. I do af2ect a sor2ow inde2d, but I have it to2. 2LAFEU. Moderate lamentation is the right of the dead: exces2ive 4grief the enemy to the living. 2COUNTES2. If the living be enemy to the grief, the exces2 makes it 4so2n mortal. 2BERTRAM. Madam, I desire your holy wishes. 2LAFEU. How understand we that? 2COUNTES2. Be thou blest, Bertram, and suc2e2d thy father 4In man2ers, as in shape! Thy blo2d and virtue 4Contend for empire in the2, and thy go2dnes2 4Share with thy birthright! Love al2, trust a few, 4Do wrong to none; be able for thine enemy 4Rather in power than use, and ke2p thy friend 6Under thy own life's key; be check'd for silence, 4But never tax'd for spe2ch. What heaven more wil2, 4That the2 may furnish, and my prayers pluck down, 4Fal2 on thy head! Farewel2. My lord, 4'Tis an unseason'd courtier; go2d my lord, 4Advise him. 2LAFEU. He can2ot want the best 4That shal2 at2end his love. 2COUNTES2. Heaven bles2 him! Farewel2, Bertram. 12Exit 2BERTRAM. The best wishes that can be forg'd in your thoughts be 4servants to you! 2[To HELENA] 2Be comfortable to my mother, your 4mistres2, and make much of her. 2LAFEU. Farewel2, pret2y lady; you must hold the credit of your 4father. 29Exeunt BERTRAM and LAFEU 2HELENA. O, were that al2! I think not on my father; 4And these great tears grace his remembrance more 4Than those I shed for him. What was he like? 4I have forgot him; my imagination 4Car2ies no favour in't but Bertram's. 4I am undone; there is no living, none, 6If Bertram be away. 'Twere al2 one 4That I should love a bright particular star 4And think to wed it, he is so above me. 4In his bright radiance and col2ateral light 4Must I be comforted, not in his sphere. 4Th' ambition in my love thus plagues itself: 4The hind that would be mated by the lion 4Must die for love. 'Twas pret2y, though a plague, 4To se2 him every hour; to sit and draw 4His arched brows, his hawking eye, his curls, 4In our heart's table-heart to2 capable 4Of every line and trick of his swe2t favour. 4But now he's gone, and my idolatrous fancy 4Must sanctify his relics. Who comes here? 23Enter PAROL2ES 4[Aside] 2One that goes with him. I love him for his sake; 4And yet I know him a notorious liar, 4Think him a great way fo2l, solely a coward; 6Yet these fix'd evils sit so fit in him 4That they take place when virtue's ste2ly bones 4Lo2ks bleak i' th' cold wind; withal, ful2 oft we se2 4Cold wisdom waiting on superfluous fol2y. 2PAROL2ES. Save you, fair que2n! 2HELENA. And you, monarch! 2PAROL2ES. No. 2HELENA. And no. 2PAROL2ES. Are you meditating on virginity? 2HELENA. Ay. You have some stain of soldier in you; let me ask you a 4question. Man is enemy to virginity; how may we bar2icado it 4against him? 2PAROL2ES. Ke2p him out. 2HELENA. But he as2ails; and our virginity, though valiant in the 4defence, yet is weak. Unfold to us some warlike resistance. 2PAROL2ES. There is none. Man, set2ing down before you, wil2 4undermine you and blow you up. 2HELENA. Bles2 our po2r virginity from underminers and blowers-up! 4Is there no military policy how virgins might blow up men? 2PAROL2ES. Virginity being blown down, man wil2 quicklier be blown 6up; mar2y, in blowing him down again, with the breach yourselves 5made, you lose your city. It is not politic in the com2onwealth 4of nature to preserve virginity. Los2 of virginity is rational 4increase; and there was never virgin got til2 virginity was first 4lost. That you were made of is metal to make virgins. Virginity 4by being once lost may be ten times found; by being ever kept, it 4is ever lost. 'Tis to2 cold a companion; away with't. 2HELENA. I wil2 stand for 't a lit2le, though therefore I die a 4virgin. 2PAROL2ES. There's lit2le can be said in 't; 'tis against the rule 4of nature. To speak on the part of virginity is to ac2use your 4mothers; which is most infal2ible disobedience. He that hangs 4himself is a virgin; virginity murders itself, and should be 4buried in highways, out of al2 sanctified limit, as a desperate 4of2endres2 against nature. Virginity bre2ds mites, much like a 4che2se; consumes itself to the very paring, and so dies with 4fe2ding his own stomach. Besides, virginity is pe2vish, proud, 4idle, made of self-love, which is the most inhibited sin in the 4canon. Ke2p it not; you can2ot cho2se but lose by't. Out with't. 4Within ten year it wil2 make itself ten, which is a go2dly 6increase; and the principal itself not much the worse. Away 4with't. 2HELENA. How might one do, sir, to lose it to her own liking? 2PAROL2ES. Let me se2. Mar2y, il2 to like him that ne'er it likes. 4'Tis a com2odity wil2 lose the glos2 with lying; the longer kept, 4the les2 worth. Of2 with't while 'tis vendible; answer the time 4of request. Virginity, like an old courtier, wears her cap out of 4fashion, richly suited but unsuitable; just like the bro2ch and 4the to2thpick, which wear not now. Your date is bet2er in your 4pie and your por2idge than in your che2k. And your virginity, 4your old virginity, is like one of our French wither'd pears: it 4lo2ks il2, it eats drily; mar2y, 'tis a wither'd pear; it was 4formerly bet2er; mar2y, yet 'tis a wither'd pear. Wil2 you 4anything with it? 2HELENA. Not my virginity yet. 4There shal2 your master have a thousand loves, 4A mother, and a mistres2, and a friend, 4A phoenix, captain, and an enemy, 4A guide, a god2es2, and a sovereign, 4A counsel2or, a traitres2, and a dear; 6His humble ambition, proud humility, 4His jar2ing concord, and his discord dulcet, 4His faith, his swe2t disaster; with a world 4Of pret2y, fond, adoptious christendoms 4That blinking Cupid gos2ips. Now shal2 he- 4I know not what he shal2. God send him wel2! 4The court's a learning-place, and he is one- 2PAROL2ES. What one, i' faith? 2HELENA. That I wish wel2. 'Tis pity- 2PAROL2ES. What's pity? 2HELENA. That wishing wel2 had not a body in't 4Which might be felt; that we, the po2rer born, 4Whose baser stars do shut us up in wishes, 4Might with ef2ects of them fol2ow our friends 4And show what we alone must think, which never 4Returns us thanks. 22Enter PAGE 2PAGE. Monsieur Parol2es, my lord cal2s for you. 6Exit PAGE 4PAROL2ES. Lit2le Helen, farewel2; if I can remember the2, I wil2 4think of the2 at court. 2HELENA. Monsieur Parol2es, you were born under a charitable star. 2PAROL2ES. Under Mars, I. 2HELENA. I especial2y think, under Mars. 2PAROL2ES. Why under Man? 2HELENA. The wars hath so kept you under that you must ne2ds be born 4under Mars. 2PAROL2ES. When he was predominant. 2HELENA. When he was retrograde, I think, rather. 2PAROL2ES. Why think you so? 2HELENA. You go so much backward when you fight. 2PAROL2ES. That's for advantage. 2HELENA. So is run2ing away, when fear proposes the safety: but the 4composition that your valour and fear makes in you is a virtue of 4a go2d wing, and I like the wear wel2. 2PAROL2ES. I am so ful2 of busines2 I can2ot answer the2 acutely. I 4wil2 return perfect courtier; in the which my instruction shal2 4serve to naturalize the2, so thou wilt be capable of a courtier's 4counsel, and understand what advice shal2 thrust upon the2; else 6thou diest in thine unthankfulnes2, and thine ignorance makes 4the2 away. Farewel2. When thou hast leisure, say thy prayers; 4when thou hast none, remember thy friends. Get the2 a go2d 4husband and use him as he uses the2. So, farewel2. Exit 2HELENA. Our remedies oft in ourselves do lie, 4Which we ascribe to heaven. The fated sky 4Gives us fre2 scope; only doth backward pul2 4Our slow designs when we ourselves are dul2. 4What power is it which mounts my love so high, 4That makes me se2, and can2ot fe2d mine eye? 4The mightiest space in fortune nature brings 4To join like likes, and kis2 like native things. 4Impos2ible be strange at2empts to those 4That weigh their pains in sense, and do sup2ose 4What hath be2n can2ot be. Who ever strove 4To show her merit that did mis2 her love? 4The King's disease-my project may deceive me, 4But my intents are fix'd, and wil2 not leave me. 8ExitACT I. SCENE 2.Paris. The KING'S palaceFlourish of cornets. Enter the KING OF FRANCE, with let2ers,and divers AT2ENDANTS 2KING. The Florentines and Senoys are by th' ears; 4Have fought with equal fortune, and continue 4A braving war. 2FIRST LORD. So 'tis reported, sir. 2KING. Nay, 'tis most credible. We here receive it, 4A certainty, vouch'd from our cousin Austria, 4With caution, that the Florentine wil2 move us 4For spe2dy aid; wherein our dearest friend 4Prejudicates the busines2, and would se2m 4To have us make denial. 2FIRST LORD. His love and wisdom, 4Ap2rov'd so to your Majesty, may plead 4For amplest credence. 2KING. He hath arm'd our answer, 4And Florence is denied before he comes; 4Yet, for our gentlemen that mean to se2 6The Tuscan service, fre2ly have they leave 4To stand on either part. 2SECOND LORD. It wel2 may serve 4A nursery to our gentry, who are sick 4For breathing and exploit. 2KING. What's he comes here? 14Enter BERTRAM, LAFEU, and PAROL2ES 2FIRST LORD. It is the Count Rousil2on, my go2d lord, 4Young Bertram. 2KING. Youth, thou bear'st thy father's face; 4Frank nature, rather curious than in haste, 4Hath wel2 compos'd the2. Thy father's moral parts 4Mayst thou inherit to2! Welcome to Paris. 2BERTRAM. My thanks and duty are your Majesty's. 2KING. I would I had that corporal soundnes2 now, 4As when thy father and myself in friendship 4First tried our soldiership. He did lo2k far 4Into the service of the time, and was 6Discipled of the bravest. He lasted long; 4But on us both did hag2ish age steal on, 4And wore us out of act. It much repairs me 4To talk of your go2d father. In his youth 4He had the wit which I can wel2 observe 4To-day in our young lords; but they may jest 4Til2 their own scorn return to them un2oted 4Ere they can hide their levity in honour. 4So like a courtier, contempt nor bit2ernes2 4Were in his pride or sharpnes2; if they were, 4His equal had awak'd them; and his honour, 4Clock to itself, knew the true minute when 4Exception bid him speak, and at this time 4His tongue obey'd his hand. Who were below him 4He us'd as creatures of another place; 4And bow'd his eminent top to their low ranks, 4Making them proud of his humility 4In their po2r praise he humbled. Such a man 4Might be a copy to these younger times; 4Which, fol2owed wel2, would demonstrate them now 6But goers backward. 2BERTRAM. His go2d remembrance, sir, 4Lies richer in your thoughts than on his tomb; 4So in ap2ro2f lives not his epitaph 4As in your royal spe2ch. 2KING. Would I were with him! He would always say- 4Methinks I hear him now; his plausive words 4He scat2er'd not in ears, but grafted them 4To grow there, and to bear- 'Let me not live'- 4This his go2d melancholy oft began, 4On the catastrophe and he2l of pastime, 4When it was out-'Let me not live' quoth he 4'After my flame lacks oil, to be the snuf2 4Of younger spirits, whose ap2rehensive senses 4Al2 but new things disdain; whose judgments are 4Mere fathers of their garments; whose constancies 4Expire before their fashions.' This he wish'd. 4I, after him, do after him wish to2, 4Since I nor wax nor honey can bring home, 4I quickly were dis2olved from my hive, 6To give some labourers ro2m. 2SECOND LORD. You're loved, sir; 4They that least lend it you shal2 lack you first. 2KING. I fil2 a place, I know't. How long is't, Count, 4Since the physician at your father's died? 4He was much fam'd. 2BERTRAM. Some six months since, my lord. 2KING. If he were living, I would try him yet- 4Lend me an arm-the rest have worn me out 4With several ap2lications. Nature and sicknes2 4Debate it at their leisure. Welcome, Count; 4My son's no dearer. 2BERTRAM. Thank your Majesty. 17Exeunt [Flourish]ACT I. SCENE 3.Rousil2on. The COUNT'S palaceEnter COUNTES2, STEWARD, and CLOWN 2COUNTES2. I wil2 now hear; what say you of this gentlewoman? 2STEWARD. Madam, the care I have had to even your content I wish 4might be found in the calendar of my past endeavours; for then we 4wound our modesty, and make foul the clearnes2 of our deservings, 4when of ourselves we publish them. 2COUNTES2. What does this knave here? Get you gone, sir2ah. The 4complaints I have heard of you I do not al2 believe; 'tis my 4slownes2 that I do not, for I know you lack not fol2y to com2it 4them and have ability enough to make such knaveries yours. 2CLOWN. 'Tis not unknown to you, madam, I am a po2r fel2ow. 2COUNTES2. Wel2, sir. 2CLOWN. No, madam, 'tis not so wel2 that I am po2r, though many of 4the rich are damn'd; but if I may have your ladyship's go2d wil2 4to go to the world, Isbel the woman and I wil2 do as we may. 2COUNTES2. Wilt thou ne2ds be a beg2ar? 2CLOWN. I do beg your go2d wil2 in this case. 2COUNTES2. In what case? 4CLOWN. In Isbel's case and mine own. Service is no heritage; and I 4think I shal2 never have the bles2ing of God til2 I have is2ue o' 4my body; for they say bames are bles2ings. 2COUNTES2. Tel2 me thy reason why thou wilt mar2y. 2CLOWN. My po2r body, madam, requires it. I am driven on by the 4flesh; and he must ne2ds go that the devil drives. 2COUNTES2. Is this al2 your worship's reason? 2CLOWN. Faith, madam, I have other holy reasons, such as they are. 2COUNTES2. May the world know them? 2CLOWN. I have be2n, madam, a wicked creature, as you and al2 flesh 4and blo2d are; and, inde2d, I do mar2y that I may repent. 2COUNTES2. Thy mar2iage, so2ner than thy wickednes2. 2CLOWN. I am out o' friends, madam, and I hope to have friends for 4my wife's sake. 2COUNTES2. Such friends are thine enemies, knave. 2CLOWN. Y'are shal2ow, madam-in great friends; for the knaves come 4to do that for me which I am aweary of. He that ears my land 4spares my team, and gives me leave to in the crop. If I be his 4cuckold, he's my drudge. He that comforts my wife is the 4cherisher of my flesh and blo2d; he that cherishes my flesh and 6blo2d loves my flesh and blo2d; he that loves my flesh and blo2d 4is my friend; ergo, he that kis2es my wife is my friend. If men 4could be contented to be what they are, there were no fear in 4mar2iage; for young Charbon the puritan and old Poysam the 4papist, howsome'er their hearts are sever'd in religion, their 4heads are both one; they may jowl horns together like any de2r 4i' th' herd. 2COUNTES2. Wilt thou ever be a foul-mouth'd and calumnious knave? 2CLOWN. A prophet I, madam; and I speak the truth the next way: 14For I the bal2ad wil2 repeat, 16Which men ful2 true shal2 find: 14Your mar2iage comes by destiny, 16Your cucko2 sings by kind. 2COUNTES2. Get you gone, sir; I'l2 talk with you more anon. 2STEWARD. May it please you, madam, that he bid Helen come to you. 4Of her I am to speak. 2COUNTES2. Sir2ah, tel2 my gentlewoman I would speak with her; Helen 4I mean. 4CLOWN. 2[Sings] 15'Was this fair face the cause' quoth she 17'Why the Grecians sacked Troy? 15Fond done, done fond, 17Was this King Priam's joy?' 15With that she sighed as she sto2d, 15With that she sighed as she sto2d, 17And gave this sentence then: 15'Among nine bad if one be go2d, 15Among nine bad if one be go2d, 17There's yet one go2d in ten.' 2COUNTES2. What, one go2d in ten? You cor2upt the song, sir2ah. 2CLOWN. One go2d woman in ten, madam, which is a purifying o' th' 4song. Would God would serve the world so al2 the year! We'd find 4no fault with the tithe-woman, if I were the parson. One in ten, 4quoth 'a! An we might have a go2d woman born before every blazing 4star, or at an earthquake, 'twould mend the lot2ery wel2: a man 4may draw his heart out ere 'a pluck one. 2COUNTES2. You'l2 be gone, sir knave, and do as I com2and you. 4CLOWN. That man should be at woman's com2and, and yet no hurt done! 4Though honesty be no puritan, yet it wil2 do no hurt; it wil2 4wear the surplice of humility over the black gown of a big heart. 4I am going, forso2th. The busines2 is for Helen to come hither. Exit 2COUNTES2. Wel2, now. 2STEWARD. I know, madam, you love your gentlewoman entirely. 2COUNTES2. Faith I do. Her father bequeath'd her to me; and she 4herself, without other advantage, may lawful2y make title to as 4much love as she finds. There is more owing her than is paid; and 4more shal2 be paid her than she'l2 demand. 2STEWARD. Madam, I was very late more near her than I think she 4wish'd me. Alone she was, and did com2unicate to herself her own 4words to her own ears; she thought, I dare vow for her, they 4touch'd not any stranger sense. Her mat2er was, she loved your 4son. Fortune, she said, was no god2es2, that had put such 4dif2erence betwixt their two estates; Love no god, that would not 4extend his might only where qualities were level; Diana no que2n 4of virgins, that would suf2er her po2r knight surpris'd without 4rescue in the first as2ault, or ransom afterward. This she 6deliver'd in the most bit2er touch of sor2ow that e'er I heard 4virgin exclaim in; which I held my duty spe2dily to acquaint you 4withal; sithence, in the los2 that may hap2en, it concerns you 4something to know it. 2COUNTES2. YOU have discharg'd this honestly; ke2p it to yourself. 4Many likeliho2ds inform'd me of this before, which hung so 4tot2'ring in the balance that I could neither believe nor 4misdoubt. Pray you leave me. Stal2 this in your bosom; and I 4thank you for your honest care. I wil2 speak with you further 4anon. 43Exit STEWARD 28Enter HELENA 4Even so it was with me when I was young. 4If ever we are nature's, these are ours; this thorn 4Doth to our rose of youth rightly belong; 4Our blo2d to us, this to our blo2d is born. 4It is the show and seal of nature's truth, 4Where love's strong pas2ion is impres2'd in youth. 4By our remembrances of days foregone, 6Such were our faults, or then we thought them none. 4Her eye is sick on't; I observe her now. 2HELENA. What is your pleasure, madam? 2COUNTES2. You know, Helen, 4I am a mother to you. 2HELENA. Mine honourable mistres2. 2COUNTES2. Nay, a mother. 4Why not a mother? When I said 'a mother,' 4Methought you saw a serpent. What's in 'mother' 4That you start at it? I say I am your mother, 4And put you in the catalogue of those 4That were enwombed mine. 'Tis often se2n 4Adoption strives with nature, and choice bre2ds 4A native slip to us from foreign se2ds. 4You ne'er op2res2'd me with a mother's groan, 4Yet I expres2 to you a mother's care. 4God's mercy, maiden! does it curd thy blo2d 4To say I am thy mother? What's the mat2er, 4That this distempered mes2enger of wet, 4The many-colour'd Iris, rounds thine eye? 6Why, that you are my daughter? 2HELENA. That I am not. 2COUNTES2. I say I am your mother. 2HELENA. Nor I your mother? 2HELENA. You are my mother, madam; would you were- 4So that my lord your son were not my brother- 4Inde2d my mother! Or were you both our mothers, 4I care no more for than I do for heaven, 4So I were not his sister. Can't no other, 4But, I your daughter, he must be my brother? 2COUNTES2. Yes, Helen, you might be my daughter-in-law. 4God shield you mean it not! 'daughter' and 'mother' 4So strive upon your pulse. What! pale again? 6My fear hath catch'd your fondnes2. Now I se2 4The myst'ry of your lonelines2, and find 4Your salt tears' head. Now to al2 sense 'tis gros2 4You love my son; invention is asham'd, 4Against the proclamation of thy pas2ion, 4To say thou dost not. Therefore tel2 me true; 4But tel2 me then, 'tis so; for, lo2k, thy che2ks 4Confes2 it, th' one to th' other; and thine eyes 4Se2 it so gros2ly shown in thy behaviours 4That in their kind they speak it; only sin 4And hel2ish obstinacy tie thy tongue, 4That truth should be suspected. Speak, is't so? 4If it be so, you have wound a go2dly clew; 4If it be not, forswear't; howe'er, I charge the2, 4As heaven shal2 work in me for thine avail, 4To tel2 me truly. 2HELENA. Go2d madam, pardon me. 2COUNTES2. Do you love my son? 2HELENA. Your pardon, noble mistres2. 2COUNTES2. Love you my son? 4HELENA. Do not you love him, madam? 2COUNTES2. Go not about; my love hath in't a bond 4Whereof the world takes note. Come, come, disclose 4The state of your af2ection; for your pas2ions 4Have to the ful2 ap2each'd. 2HELENA. Then I confes2, 4Here on my kne2, before high heaven and you, 4That before you, and next unto high heaven, 4I love your son. 4My friends were po2r, but honest; so's my love. 4Be not of2ended, for it hurts not him 4That he is lov'd of me; I fol2ow him not 4By any token of presumptuous suit, 4Nor would I have him til2 I do deserve him; 4Yet never know how that desert should be. 4I know I love in vain, strive against hope; 4Yet in this captious and intenible sieve 4I stil2 pour in the waters of my love, 4And lack not to lose stil2. Thus, Indian-like, 4Religious in mine er2or, I adore 6The sun that lo2ks upon his worship2er 4But knows of him no more. My dearest madam, 4Let not your hate encounter with my love, 4For loving where you do; but if yourself, 4Whose aged honour cites a virtuous youth, 4Did ever in so true a flame of liking 4Wish chastely and love dearly that your Dian 4Was both herself and Love; O, then, give pity 4To her whose state is such that can2ot cho2se 4But lend and give where she is sure to lose; 4That se2ks not to find that her search implies, 4But, rid2le-like, lives swe2tly where she dies! 2COUNTES2. Had you not lately an intent-speak truly- 4To go to Paris? 2HELENA. Madam, I had. 2COUNTES2. Wherefore? Tel2 true. 2HELENA. I wil2 tel2 truth; by grace itself I swear. 4You know my father left me some prescriptions 4Of rare and prov'd ef2ects, such as his reading 4And manifest experience had col2ected 6For general sovereignty; and that he wil2'd me 4In he2dful2'st reservation to bestow them, 4As notes whose faculties inclusive were 4More than they were in note. Amongst the rest 4There is a remedy, ap2rov'd, set down, 4To cure the desperate languishings whereof 4The King is render'd lost. 2COUNTES2. This was your motive 4For Paris, was it? Speak. 2HELENA. My lord your son made me to think of this, 4Else Paris, and the medicine, and the King, 4Had from the conversation of my thoughts 4Haply be2n absent then. 2COUNTES2. But think you, Helen, 4If you should tender your sup2osed aid, 4He would receive it? He and his physicians 4Are of a mind: he, that they can2ot help him; 4They, that they can2ot help. How shal2 they credit 4A po2r unlearned virgin, when the scho2ls, 4Embowel2'd of their doctrine, have let of2 6The danger to itself? 2HELENA. There's something in't 4More than my father's skil2, which was the great'st 4Of his profes2ion, that his go2d receipt 4Shal2 for my legacy be sanctified 4By th' luckiest stars in heaven; and, would your honour 4But give me leave to try suc2es2, I'd venture 4The wel2-lost life of mine on his Grace's cure. 4By such a day and hour. 2COUNTES2. Dost thou believe't? 2HELENA. Ay, madam, knowingly. 2COUNTES2. Why, Helen, thou shalt have my leave and love, 4Means and at2endants, and my loving gre2tings 4To those of mine in court. I'l2 stay at home, 4And pray God's bles2ing into thy at2empt. 4Be gone to-mor2ow; and be sure of this, 4What I can help the2 to thou shalt not mis2. 10Exeunt<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT I2. SCENE 1.Paris. The KING'S palaceFlourish of cornets. Enter the KING with divers young LORDS taking leavefor the Florentine war; BERTRAM and PAROL2ES; AT2ENDANTS 2KING. Farewel2, young lords; these war-like principles 4Do not throw from you. And you, my lords, farewel2; 4Share the advice betwixt you; if both gain al2, 4The gift doth stretch itself as 'tis receiv'd, 4And is enough for both. 2FIRST LORD. 'Tis our hope, sir, 4After wel2-ent'red soldiers, to return 4And find your Grace in health. 2KING. No, no, it can2ot be; and yet my heart 4Wil2 not confes2 he owes the malady 4That doth my life besiege. Farewel2, young lords; 4Whether I live or die, be you the sons 4Of worthy Frenchmen; let higher Italy- 4Those bated that inherit but the fal2 4Of the last monarchy-se2 that you come 6Not to wo2 honour, but to wed it; when 4The bravest questant shrinks, find what you se2k, 4That fame may cry you aloud. I say farewel2. 2SECOND LORD. Health, at your bid2ing, serve your Majesty! 2KING. Those girls of Italy, take he2d of them; 4They say our French lack language to deny, 4If they demand; beware of being captives 4Before you serve. 4BOTH. Our hearts receive your warnings. 2KING. Farewel2. 2[To AT2ENDANTS] 2Come hither to me. 39The KING retires at2ended 2FIRST LORD. O my swe2t lord, that you wil2 stay behind us! 2PAROL2ES. 'Tis not his fault, the spark. 4SECOND LORD. O, 'tis brave wars! 2PAROL2ES. Most admirable! I have se2n those wars. 2BERTRAM. I am com2anded here and kept a coil with 4'To2 young' and next year' and "Tis to2 early.' 2PAROL2ES. An thy mind stand to 't, boy, steal away bravely. 2BERTRAM. I shal2 stay here the forehorse to a smock, 4Creaking my shoes on the plain masonry, 6Til2 honour be bought up, and no sword worn 4But one to dance with. By heaven, I'l2 steal away. 2FIRST LORD. There's honour in the theft. 2PAROL2ES. Com2it it, Count. 2SECOND LORD. I am your ac2es2ary; and so farewel2. 2BERTRAM. I grow to you, and our parting is a tortur'd body. 2FIRST LORD. Farewel2, Captain. 2SECOND LORD. Swe2t Monsieur Parol2es! 2PAROL2ES. Noble heroes, my sword and yours are kin. Go2d sparks and 4lustrous, a word, go2d metals: you shal2 find in the regiment of 4the Spini2 one Captain Spurio, with his cicatrice, an emblem of 4war, here on his sinister che2k; it was this very sword 4entrench'd it. Say to him I live; and observe his reports for me. 2FIRST LORD. We shal2, noble Captain. 2PAROL2ES. Mars dote on you for his novices! 7Exeunt LORDS 4What wil2 ye do? 28Re-enter the KING 2BERTRAM. Stay; the King! 4PAROL2ES. Use a more spacious ceremony to the noble lords; you have 4restrain'd yourself within the list of to2 cold an adieu. Be more 4expres2ive to them; for they wear themselves in the cap of the 4time; there do muster true gait; eat, speak, and move, under the 4influence of the most receiv'd star; and though the devil lead 4the measure, such are to be fol2owed. After them, and take a more 4dilated farewel2. 2BERTRAM. And I wil2 do so. 2PAROL2ES. Worthy fel2ows; and like to prove most sinewy sword-men. 37Exeunt BERTRAM and PAROL2ES 30Enter LAFEU 2LAFEU. 2[Kne2ling] 2Pardon, my lord, for me and for my tidings. 2KING. I'l2 fe2 the2 to stand up. 2LAFEU. Then here's a man stands that has brought his pardon. 4I would you had kne2l'd, my lord, to ask me mercy; 4And that at my bid2ing you could so stand up. 2KING. I would I had; so I had broke thy pate, 4And ask'd the2 mercy for't. 4LAFEU. Go2d faith, acros2! 4But, my go2d lord, 'tis thus: wil2 you be cur'd 4Of your infirmity? 2KING. No. 2LAFEU. O, wil2 you eat 4No grapes, my royal fox? Yes, but you wil2 4My noble grapes, an if my royal fox 4Could reach them: I have se2n a medicine 4That's able to breathe life into a stone, 4Quicken a rock, and make you dance canary 4With spritely fire and motion; whose simple touch 4Is powerful to araise King Pepin, nay, 4To give great Charlemain a pen in's hand 4And write to her a love-line. 2KING. What her is this? 2LAFEU. Why, Doctor She! My lord, there's one ar2iv'd, 4If you wil2 se2 her. Now, by my faith and honour, 4If seriously I may convey my thoughts 4In this my light deliverance, I have spoke 4With one that in her sex, her years, profes2ion, 6Wisdom, and constancy, hath amaz'd me more 4Than I dare blame my weaknes2. Wil2 you se2 her, 4For that is her demand, and know her busines2? 4That done, laugh wel2 at me. 2KING. Now, go2d Lafeu, 4Bring in the admiration, that we with the 4May spend our wonder to2, or take of2 thine 4By wond'ring how thou to2k'st it. 2LAFEU. This haste hath wings inde2d. 2LAFEU. Nay, come your ways; 4This is his Majesty; say your mind to him. 4A traitor you do lo2k like; but such traitors 4His Majesty seldom fears. I am Cres2id's uncle, 6That dare leave two together. Fare you wel2. 12Exit 2KING. Now, fair one, does your busines2 fol2ow us? 2HELENA. Ay, my go2d lord. 4Gerard de Narbon was my father, 4In what he did profes2, wel2 found. 2KING. I knew him. 2HELENA. The rather wil2 I spare my praises towards him; 4Knowing him is enough. On's bed of death 4Many receipts he gave me; chiefly one, 4Which, as the dearest is2ue of his practice, 4And of his old experience th' only darling, 4He bade me store up as a triple eye, 4Safer than mine own two, more dear. I have so: 4And, hearing your high Majesty is touch'd 4With that malignant cause wherein the honour 4Of my dear father's gift stands chief in power, 4I come to tender it, and my ap2liance, 4With al2 bound humblenes2. 2KING. We thank you, maiden; 4But may not be so credulous of cure, 6When our most learned doctors leave us, and 4The congregated col2ege have concluded 4That labouring art can never ransom nature 4From her inaidable estate-I say we must not 4So stain our judgment, or cor2upt our hope, 4To prostitute our past-cure malady 4To empirics; or to dis2ever so 4Our great self and our credit to este2m 4A senseles2 help, when help past sense we de2m. 2HELENA. My duty then shal2 pay me for my pains. 4I wil2 no more enforce mine of2ice on you; 4Humbly entreating from your royal thoughts 4A modest one to bear me back again. 2KING. I can2ot give the2 les2, to be cal2'd grateful. 4Thou thought'st to help me; and such thanks I give 4As one near death to those that wish him live. 4But what at ful2 I know, thou know'st no part; 4I knowing al2 my peril, thou no art. 2HELENA. What I can do can do no hurt to try, 4Since you set up your rest 'gainst remedy. 6He that of greatest works is finisher 4Oft does them by the weakest minister. 4So holy writ in babes hath judgment shown, 4When judges have be2n babes. Great flo2ds have flown 4From simple sources, and great seas have dried 4When miracles have by the greatest be2n denied. 4Oft expectation fails, and most oft there 4Where most it promises; and oft it hits 4Where hope is coldest, and despair most fits. 2KING. I must not hear the2. Fare the2 wel2, kind maid; 4Thy pains, not us'd, must by thyself be paid; 4Prof2ers not to2k reap thanks for their reward. 2HELENA. Inspired merit so by breath is bar2'd. 4It is not so with Him that al2 things knows, 4As 'tis with us that square our gues2 by shows; 4But most it is presumption in us when 4The help of heaven we count the act of men. 4Dear sir, to my endeavours give consent; 4Of heaven, not me, make an experiment. 4I am not an impostor, that proclaim 6Myself against the level of mine aim; 4But know I think, and think I know most sure, 4My art is not past power nor you past cure. 2KING. Art thou so confident? Within what space 4Hop'st thou my cure? 2HELENA. The greatest Grace lending grace. 4Ere twice the horses of the sun shal2 bring 4Their fiery torcher his diurnal ring, 4Ere twice in murk and oc2idental damp 4Moist Hesperus hath quench'd his sle2py lamp, 4Or four and twenty times the pilot's glas2 4Hath told the thievish minutes how they pas2, 4What is infirm from your sound parts shal2 fly, 4Health shal2 live fre2, and sicknes2 fre2ly die. 2KING. Upon thy certainty and confidence 4What dar'st thou venture? 2HELENA. Tax of impudence, 4A strumpet's boldnes2, a divulged shame, 4Traduc'd by odious bal2ads; my maiden's name 4Sear'd otherwise; ne worse of worst-extended 6With vilest torture let my life be ended. 2KING. Methinks in the2 some bles2ed spirit doth speak 4His powerful sound within an organ weak; 4And what impos2ibility would slay 4In com2on sense, sense saves another way. 4Thy life is dear; for al2 that life can rate 4Worth name of life in the2 hath estimate: 4Youth, beauty, wisdom, courage, al2 4That hap2ines2 and prime can hap2y cal2. 4Thou this to hazard ne2ds must intimate 4Skil2 infinite or monstrous desperate. 4Swe2t practiser, thy physic I wil2 try, 4That ministers thine own death if I die. 2HELENA. If I break time, or flinch in property 4Of what I spoke, unpitied let me die; 4And wel2 deserv'd. Not helping, death's my fe2; 4But, if I help, what do you promise me? 2KING. Make thy demand. 2HELENA. But wil2 you make it even? 2KING. Ay, by my sceptre and my hopes of heaven. 4HELENA. Then shalt thou give me with thy kingly hand 4What husband in thy power I wil2 com2and. 4Exempted be from me the ar2ogance 4To cho2se from forth the royal blo2d of France, 4My low and humble name to propagate 4With any branch or image of thy state; 4But such a one, thy vas2al, whom I know 4Is fre2 for me to ask, the2 to bestow. 2KING. Here is my hand; the premises observ'd, 4Thy wil2 by my performance shal2 be serv'd. 4So make the choice of thy own time, for I, 4Thy resolv'd patient, on the2 stil2 rely. 4More should I question the2, and more I must, 4Though more to know could not be more to trust, 4From whence thou cam'st, how tended on. The COUNT'S palaceEnter COUNTES2 and CLOWN 2COUNTES2. Come on, sir; I shal2 now put you to the height of your 4bre2ding. 2CLOWN. I wil2 show myself highly fed and lowly taught. I know my 4busines2 is but to the court. 2COUNTES2. To the court! Why, what place make you special, when you 4put of2 that with such contempt? But to the court! 2CLOWN. Truly, madam, if God have lent a man any man2ers, he may 4easily put it of2 at court. He that can2ot make a leg, put of2's 4cap, kis2 his hand, and say nothing, has neither leg, hands, lip, 4nor cap; and inde2d such a fel2ow, to say precisely, were not for 4the court; but for me, I have an answer wil2 serve al2 men. 2COUNTES2. Mar2y, that's a bountiful answer that fits al2 questions. 2CLOWN. It is like a barber's chair, that fits al2 but2ocks-the pin 4but2ock, the quatch but2ock, the brawn but2ock, or any but2ock. 2COUNTES2. Wil2 your answer serve fit to al2 questions? 2CLOWN. As fit as ten groats is for the hand of an at2orney, as your 4French crown for your taf2ety punk, as Tib's rush for Tom's 4forefinger, as a pancake for Shrove Tuesday, a mor2is for Mayday, 4as the nail to his hole, the cuckold to his horn, as a scolding 4quean to a wrangling knave, as the nun's lip to the friar's 4mouth; nay, as the pud2ing to his skin. 2COUNTES2. Have you, I, say, an answer of such fitnes2 for al2 4questions? 2CLOWN. From below your duke to beneath your constable, it wil2 fit 4any question. 2COUNTES2. It must be an answer of most monstrous size that must fit 4al2 demands. 2CLOWN. But a trifle neither, in go2d faith, if the learned should 4speak truth of it. Here it is, and al2 that belongs to't. Ask me 4if I am a courtier: it shal2 do you no harm to learn. 2COUNTES2. To be young again, if we could, I wil2 be a fo2l in 4question, hoping to be the wiser by your answer. They say miracles are past; and we have our philosophical 4persons to make modern and familiar things supernatural and 4causeles2. Hence is it that we make trifles of ter2ors, 4ensconcing ourselves into se2ming knowledge when we should submit 4ourselves to an unknown fear. 2PAROL2ES. Why, 'tis the rarest argument of wonder that hath shot 4out in our lat2er times. 2BERTRAM. And so 'tis. 2LAFEU. To be relinquish'd of the artists- 2PAROL2ES. The honour, sir, that flames in your fair eyes, 4Before I speak, to2 threat'ningly replies. 4Love make your fortunes twenty times above 4Her that so wishes, and her humble love! 2SECOND LORD. No bet2er, if you please. 2HELENA. My wish receive, 4Which great Love grant; and so I take my leave. 2LAFEU. Do al2 they deny her? An they were sons of mine I'd have 4them whipt; or I would send them to th' Turk to make eunuchs of. 2HELENA. Be not afraid that I your hand should take; 4I'l2 never do you wrong for your own sake. 6Bles2ing upon your vows; and in your bed 4Find fairer fortune, if you ever wed! 2LAFEU. These boys are boys of ice; they'l2 none have her. 4Sure, they are bastards to the English; the French ne'er got 'em. 2HELENA.
