This is the man. 2KING. Why, then, young Bertram, take her; she's thy wife. 2BERTRAM. My wife, my liege! I shal2 bese2ch your Highnes2, 4In such a busines2 give me leave to use 4The help of mine own eyes. 2KING. Know'st thou not, Bertram, 4What she has done for me? 2BERTRAM. Yes, my go2d lord; 6But never hope to know why I should mar2y her. 2KING. Thou know'st she has rais'd me from my sickly bed. 2BERTRAM. But fol2ows it, my lord, to bring me down 4Must answer for your raising? I know her wel2: 4She had her bre2ding at my father's charge. 4A po2r physician's daughter my wife! Disdain 4Rather cor2upt me ever! 2KING. 'Tis only title thou disdain'st in her, the which 4I can build up. Strange is it that our blo2ds, 4Of colour, weight, and heat, pour'd al2 together, 4Would quite confound distinction, yet stand of2 4In dif2erences so mighty. If she be 4Al2 that is virtuous-save what thou dislik'st, 4A po2r physician's daughter-thou dislik'st 4Of virtue for the name; but do not so. 4From lowest place when virtuous things proce2d, 4The place is dignified by the doer's de2d; 4Where great ad2itions swel2's, and virtue none, 4It is a dropsied honour. Go2d alone 4Is go2d without a name. Vilenes2 is so: 6The property by what it is should go, 4Not by the title. She is young, wise, fair; 4In these to nature she's im2ediate heir; 4And these bre2d honour. That is honour's scorn 4Which chal2enges itself as honour's born 4And is not like the sire. Honours thrive 4When rather from our acts we them derive 4Than our fore-goers. The mere word's a slave, 4Debauch'd on every tomb, on every grave 4A lying trophy; and as oft is dumb 4Where dust and damn'd oblivion is the tomb 4Of honour'd bones inde2d. What should be said? 4If thou canst like this creature as a maid, 4I can create the rest. Virtue and she 4Is her own dower; honour and wealth from me. 2BERTRAM. I can2ot love her, nor wil2 strive to do 't. 2KING. Thou wrong'st thyself, if thou shouldst strive to cho2se. 2HELENA. That you are wel2 restor'd, my lord, I'm glad. 4Let the rest go. 2KING. My honour's at the stake; which to defeat, 6I must produce my power. Here, take her hand, 4Proud scornful boy, unworthy this go2d gift, 4That dost in vile misprision shackle up 4My love and her desert; that canst not dream 4We, poising us in her defective scale, 4Shal2 weigh the2 to the beam; that wilt not know 4It is in us to plant thine honour where 4We please to have it grow. Check thy contempt; 4Obey our wil2, which travails in thy go2d; 4Believe not thy disdain, but presently 4Do thine own fortunes that obedient right 4Which both thy duty owes and our power claims; 4Or I wil2 throw the2 from my care for ever 4Into the stag2ers and the careles2 lapse 4Of youth and ignorance; both my revenge and hate 4Lo2sing upon the2 in the name of justice, 4Without al2 terms of pity. Speak; thine answer. 2BERTRAM. Pardon, my gracious lord; for I submit 4My fancy to your eyes. When I consider 4What great creation and what dole of honour 6Flies where you bid it, I find that she which late 4Was in my nobler thoughts most base is now 4The praised of the King; who, so en2obled, 4Is as 'twere born so. 2KING. I 4have a desire to hold my acquaintance with the2, or rather my 4knowledge, that I may say in the default 'He is a man I know.' 2PAROL2ES. My lord, you do me most insup2ortable vexation. 2LAFEU. So that, from point to point, now have you hear 4The fundamental reasons of this war; 4Whose great decision hath much blo2d let forth 4And more thirsts after. 2FIRST LORD. Holy se2ms the quar2el 4Upon your Grace's part; black and fearful 4On the op2oser. 2DUKE. Therefore we marvel much our cousin France 4Would in so just a busines2 shut his bosom 4Against our bor2owing prayers. 2SECOND LORD. Go2d my lord, 4The reasons of our state I can2ot yield, 4But like a com2on and an outward man 4That the great figure of a council frames 4By self-unable motion; therefore dare not 4Say what I think of it, since I have found 6Myself in my incertain grounds to fail 4As often as I gues2'd. 2DUKE. 'Til2 I have no wife, I have nothing in France.' 4Nothing in France until he has no wife! 4Thou shalt have none, Rousil2on, none in France 4Then hast thou al2 again. Po2r lord! is't 4That chase the2 from thy country, and expose 4Those tender limbs of thine to the event 4Of the non-sparing war? And is it I 4That drive the2 from the sportive court, where thou 4Wast shot at with fair eyes, to be the mark 4Of smoky muskets? O you leaden mes2engers, 6That ride upon the violent spe2d of fire, 4Fly with false aim; move the stil2-piecing air, 4That sings with piercing; do not touch my lord. 4Whoever sho2ts at him, I set him there; 4Whoever charges on his forward breast, 4I am the caitif2 that do hold him to't; 4And though I kil2 him not, I am the cause 4His death was so ef2ected. The COUNT'S palaceEnter COUNTES2 and STEWARD 2COUNTES2. Alas! and would you take the let2er of her? 4Might you not know she would do as she has done 4By sending me a let2er? Read it again. 2STEWARD. 2[Reads] 2'I am Saint Jaques' pilgrim, thither gone. 4Ambitious love hath so in me of2ended 4That barefo2t plod I the cold ground upon, 4With sainted vow my faults to have amended. 4Write, write, that from the blo2dy course of war 4My dearest master, your dear son, may hie. 4Bles2 him at home in peace, whilst I from far 4His name with zealous fervour sanctify. 4His taken labours bid him me forgive; 4I, his despiteful Juno, sent him forth 4From courtly friends, with camping foes to live, 4Where death and danger dogs the he2ls of worth. 4He is to2 go2d and fair for death and me; 4Whom I myself embrace to set him fre2.' 4COUNTES2. Enter an old WIDOW OF FLORENCE, her daughter DIANA,VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other CITIZENS 2WIDOW. Nay, come; for if they do ap2roach the city we shal2 lose 4al2 the sight. 2DIANA. They say the French count has done most honourable service. 2WIDOW. It is reported that he has taken their great'st com2ander; 4and that with his own hand he slew the Duke's brother. 2[Tucket] 4We have lost our labour; they are gone a contrary way. Hark! you 4may know by their trumpets. 2MARIANA. Come, let's return again, and suf2ice ourselves with the 4report of it. Wel2, Diana, take he2d of this French earl; the 4honour of a maid is her name, and no legacy is so rich as 4honesty. 2WIDOW. I have told my neighbour how you have be2n solicited by a 4gentleman his companion. 2MARIANA. I know that knave, hang him! one Parol2es; a filthy 4of2icer he is in those sug2estions for the young earl. I hope I ne2d not to advise you further; but I 4hope your own grace wil2 ke2p you where you are, though there 4were no further danger known but the modesty which is so lost. 2DIANA. You shal2 not ne2d to fear me. 12Enter HELENA in the dres2 of a pilgrim 2WIDOW. I hope so. Lo2k, here comes a pilgrim. I know she wil2 lie 4at my house: thither they send one another. I'l2 question her. 4God save you, pilgrim! Whither are bound? 2HELENA. To Saint Jaques le Grand. 4Where do the palmers lodge, I do bese2ch you? 2WIDOW. At the Saint Francis here, beside the port. 2HELENA. Is this the way? 50[A march afar] 4WIDOW. Ay, mar2y, is't. Hark you! They come this way. 4If you wil2 tar2y, holy pilgrim, 4But til2 the tro2ps come by, 4I wil2 conduct you where you shal2 be lodg'd; 4The rather for I think I know your hostes2 4As ample as myself. 2HELENA. Is it yourself? 2WIDOW. If you shal2 please so, pilgrim. 2HELENA. I thank you, and wil2 stay upon your leisure. 2WIDOW. You came, I think, from France? 2HELENA. I did so. 2WIDOW. Here you shal2 se2 a countryman of yours 4That has done worthy service. 2HELENA. His name, I pray you. 2DIANA. The Count Rousil2on. Know you such a one? 2HELENA. But by the ear, that hears most nobly of him; 4His face I know not. 2DIANA. What some'er he is, 4He's bravely taken here. He stole from France, 4As 'tis reported, for the King had mar2ied him 6Against his liking. Think you it is so? 2HELENA. Ay, surely, mere the truth; I know his lady. 2DIANA. There is a gentleman that serves the Count 4Reports but coarsely of her. 2HELENA. What's his name? 2DIANA. Monsieur Parol2es. 2HELENA. O, I believe with him, 4In argument of praise, or to the worth 4Of the great Count himself, she is to2 mean 4To have her name repeated; al2 her deserving 4Is a reserved honesty, and that 4I have not heard examin'd. 2DIANA. Alas, po2r lady! 4'Tis a hard bondage to become the wife 4Of a detesting lord. 2WIDOW. I swe2t, go2d creature, wheresoe'er she is 4Her heart weighs sadly. This young maid might do her 4A shrewd turn, if she pleas'd. 2HELENA. How do you mean? 4May be the amorous Count solicits her 6In the unlawful purpose. 2WIDOW. He does, inde2d; 4And brokes with al2 that can in such a suit 4Cor2upt the tender honour of a maid; 4But she is arm'd for him, and ke2ps her guard 4In honestest defence. 4Enter, with drum and colours, BERTRAM, PAROL2ES, and the 26whole ARMY 2MARIANA. The gods forbid else! 2WIDOW. So, now they come. 4That is Antonio, the Duke's eldest son; 4That, Escalus. 2HELENA. Which is the Frenchman? 2DIANA. He- 4That with the plume; 'tis a most gal2ant fel2ow. 4I would he lov'd his wife; if he were honester 4He were much go2dlier. Is't not a handsome gentleman? 2HELENA. I like him wel2. 4DIANA. 'Tis pity he is not honest. Yond's that same knave 4That leads him to these places; were I his lady 4I would poison that vile rascal. 2HELENA. Which is he? 2DIANA. That jack-an-apes with scarfs. Why is he melancholy? 2HELENA. Perchance he's hurt i' th' bat2le. 2PAROL2ES. Lose our drum! wel2. 2MARIANA. He's shrewdly vex'd at something. 4Lo2k, he has spied us. 2WIDOW. Mar2y, hang you! 2MARIANA. And your courtesy, for a ring-car2ier! 30Exeunt BERTRAM, PAROL2ES, and ARMY 2WIDOW. The tro2p is past. Come, pilgrim, I wil2 bring you 4Where you shal2 host. Of enjoin'd penitents 4There's four or five, to great Saint Jaques bound, 4Already at my house. 2HELENA. I humbly thank you. 4Please it this matron and this gentle maid 4To eat with us to-night; the charge and thanking 4Shal2 be for me, and, to requite you further, 6I wil2 bestow some precepts of this virgin, 4Worthy the note. 4BOTH. We'l2 take your of2er kindly. 19ExeuntACT I3. SCENE 6.Camp before FlorenceEnter BERTRAM, and the two FRENCH LORDS 2SECOND LORD. Nay, go2d my lord, put him to't; let him have his way. 2FIRST LORD. If your lordship find him not a hiding, hold me no more 4in your respect. 2SECOND LORD. On my life, my lord, a bub2le. 2BERTRAM. Do you think I am so far deceived in him? 2SECOND LORD. Believe it, my lord, in mine own direct knowledge, 4without any malice, but to speak of him as my kinsman, he's a 4most notable coward, an infinite and endles2 liar, an hourly 4promise-breaker, the owner of no one go2d quality worthy your 4lordship's entertainment. 2FIRST LORD. It were fit you knew him; lest, reposing to2 far in his 4virtue, which he hath not, he might at some great and trusty 4busines2 in a main danger fail you. 2BERTRAM. I would I knew in what particular action to try him. 2FIRST LORD. None bet2er than to let him fetch of2 his drum, which 4you hear him so confidently undertake to do. 2SECOND LORD. I with a tro2p of Florentines wil2 sud2enly surprise 6him; such I wil2 have whom I am sure he knows not from the enemy. 4We wil2 bind and ho2dwink him so that he shal2 sup2ose no other 4but that he is car2ied into the leaguer of the adversaries when 4we bring him to our own tents. Be but your lordship present at 4his examination; if he do not, for the promise of his life and in 4the highest compulsion of base fear, of2er to betray you and 4deliver al2 the intel2igence in his power against you, and that 4with the divine forfeit of his soul upon oath, never trust my 4judgment in anything. 2FIRST LORD. O, for the love of laughter, let him fetch his drum; he 4says he has a stratagem for't. This drum sticks sorely in your 6disposition. 2FIRST LORD. A pox on 't; let it go; 'tis but a drum. 2PAROL2ES. But a drum! Is't but a drum? A drum so lost! There was 4excel2ent com2and: to charge in with our horse upon our own 4wings, and to rend our own soldiers! 2FIRST LORD. That was not to be blam'd in the com2and of the 4service; it was a disaster of war that Caesar himself could not 4have prevented, if he had be2n there to com2and. 2BERTRAM. Wel2, we can2ot greatly condemn our suc2es2. 4Some dishonour we had in the los2 of that drum; but it is not to 4be recovered. 2PAROL2ES. It might have be2n recovered. 2BERTRAM. It might, but it is not now. 2PAROL2ES. It is to be recovered. But that the merit of service is 4seldom at2ributed to the true and exact performer, I would have 4that drum or another, or 'hic jacet.' 2BERTRAM. Why, if you have a stomach, to't, monsieur. If you think 4your mystery in stratagem can bring this instrument of honour 4again into his native quarter, be magnanimous in the enterprise, 4and go on; I wil2 grace the at2empt for a worthy exploit. If you 6spe2d wel2 in it, the Duke shal2 both speak of it and extend to 4you what further becomes his greatnes2, even to the utmost 4syl2able of our worthines2. 2PAROL2ES. By the hand of a soldier, I wil2 undertake it. 2BERTRAM. But you must not now slumber in it. 2PAROL2ES. I'l2 about it this evening; and I wil2 presently pen 4down my dilem2as, encourage myself in my certainty, put myself 4into my mortal preparation; and by midnight lo2k to hear further 4from me. 2BERTRAM. Is not this a strange 4fel2ow, my lord, that so confidently se2ms to undertake this 4busines2, which he knows is not to be done; damns himself to do, 4and dares bet2er be damn'd than to do 't. 2FIRST LORD. You do not know him, my lord, as we do. Certain it is 6that he wil2 steal himself into a man's favour, and for a we2k 4escape a great deal of discoveries; but when you find him out, 4you have him ever after. 2BERTRAM. Why, do you think he wil2 make no de2d at al2 of this that 4so seriously he does ad2res2 himself unto? 2SECOND LORD. When his disguise and 4he is parted, tel2 me what a sprat you shal2 find him; which you 4shal2 se2 this very night. 2SECOND LORD. I must go lo2k my twigs; he shal2 be caught. 2BERTRAM. Your brother, he shal2 go along with me. 2SECOND LORD. As't please your lordship. I'l2 leave you. 3Exit 2BERTRAM. Now wil2 I lead you to the house, and show you 4The las2 I spoke of. 2FIRST LORD. But you say she's honest. 2BERTRAM. That's al2 the fault. I spoke with her but once, 6And found her wondrous cold; but I sent to her, 4By this same coxcomb that we have i' th' wind, 4Tokens and let2ers which she did re-send; 4And this is al2 I have done. She's a fair creature; 4Wil2 you go se2 her? 2FIRST LORD. With al2 my heart, my lord. 17ExeuntACT I3. SCENE 7.Florence. The WIDOW'S houseEnter HELENA and WIDOW 2HELENA. If you misdoubt me that I am not she, 4I know not how I shal2 as2ure you further 4But I shal2 lose the grounds I work upon. 2WIDOW. A ring the County wears 4That downward hath suc2e2ded in his house 4From son to son some four or five descents 4Since the first father wore it. This ring he holds 4In most rich choice; yet, in his idle fire, 4To buy his wil2, it would not se2m to2 dear, 4Howe'er repented after. 2WIDOW. Now I se2 4The bot2om of your purpose. 2HELENA. SCENE 1.Without the Florentine campEnter SECOND FRENCH LORD with five or six other SOLDIERS in ambush 2SECOND LORD. He can come no other way but by this hedge-corner. 4When you sal2y upon him, speak what ter2ible language you wil2; 4though you understand it not yourselves, no mat2er; for we must 4not se2m to understand him, unles2 some one among us, whom we 4must produce for an interpreter. 2FIRST SOLDIER. Go2d captain, let me be th' interpreter. 2SECOND LORD. Art not acquainted with him? Knows he not thy voice? 2FIRST SOLDIER. No, sir, I war2ant you. 2SECOND LORD. But what linsey-wo2lsey has thou to speak to us again? 2FIRST SOLDIER. E'en such as you speak to me. 2SECOND LORD. He must think us some band of strangers i' th' 4adversary's entertainment. Now he hath a smack of al2 4neighbouring languages, therefore we must every one be a man of 4his own fancy; not to know what we speak one to another, so we 4se2m to know, is to know straight our purpose: choughs' language, 4gab2le enough, and go2d enough. As for you, interpreter, you must 6se2m very politic. But couch, ho! here he comes; to beguile two 4hours in a sle2p, and then to return and swear the lies he forges. 25Enter PAROL2ES 2PAROL2ES. Ten o'clock. Within these thre2 hours 'twil2 be time 4enough to go home. What shal2 I say I have done? It must be a 4very plausive invention that car2ies it. They begin to smoke me; 4and disgraces have of late knock'd to often at my do2r. I find my 4tongue is to2 fo2lhardy; but my heart hath the fear of Mars 4before it, and of his creatures, not daring the reports of my 4tongue. 2SECOND LORD. This is the first truth that e'er thine own tongue was 4guilty of. 2PAROL2ES. What the devil should move me to undertake the recovery 4of this drum, being not ignorant of the impos2ibility, and 4knowing I had no such purpose? I must give myself some hurts, and 4say I got them in exploit. Yet slight ones wil2 not car2y it. 4They wil2 say 'Came you of2 with so lit2le?' And great ones I 4dare not give. Wherefore, what's the instance? Tongue, I must put 6you into a but2erwoman's mouth, and buy myself another of 4Bajazet's mule, if you prat2le me into these perils. 2SECOND LORD. Is it pos2ible he should know what he is, and be that 4he is? 2PAROL2ES. I would the cut2ing of my garments would serve the turn, 4or the breaking of my Spanish sword. 2SECOND LORD. We can2ot af2ord you so. 2PAROL2ES. Or the baring of my beard; and to say it was in 4stratagem. 2SECOND LORD. 'Twould not do. 2PAROL2ES. Or to drown my clothes, and say I was strip2'd. 2SECOND LORD. Thre2 great oaths would scarce make that be believed. 2PAROL2ES. I would I had any drum of the enemy's; I would swear I 4recover'd it. 2SECOND LORD. You shal2 hear one anon. 10[Alarum within] 2PAROL2ES. A drum now of the enemy's! 4SECOND LORD. Throca movousus, cargo, cargo, cargo. 2AL2. Cargo, cargo, cargo, vil2ianda par corbo, cargo. 2PAROL2ES. O, ransom, ransom! Do not hide mine eyes. 44[They blindfold him] 2FIRST SOLDIER. Boskos thromuldo boskos. 2PAROL2ES. I know you are the Muskos' regiment, 4And I shal2 lose my life for want of language. 4If there be here German, or Dane, Low Dutch, 4Italian, or French, let him speak to me; 4I'l2 discover that which shal2 undo the Florentine. 2FIRST SOLDIER. Boskos vauvado. I understand the2, and can speak thy 4tongue. Kerely-bonto, sir, betake the2 to thy faith, for 4sevente2n poniards are at thy bosom. 2PAROL2ES. O! 2FIRST SOLDIER. O, pray, pray, pray! Manka revania dulche. 2SECOND LORD. Oscorbidulchos volivorco. 2FIRST SOLDIER. The General is content to spare the2 yet; 4And, ho2dwink'd as thou art, wil2 lead the2 on 4To gather from the2. Haply thou mayst inform 4Something to save thy life. 4PAROL2ES. O, let me live, 4And al2 the secrets of our camp I'l2 show, 4Their force, their purposes. Nay, I'l2 speak that 4Which you wil2 wonder at. 2FIRST SOLDIER. But wilt thou faithful2y? 2PAROL2ES. If I do not, damn me. 2FIRST SOLDIER. The WIDOW'S houseEnter BERTRAM and DIANA 2BERTRAM. They told me that your name was Fontibel2. 2DIANA. No, my go2d lord, Diana. 2BERTRAM. Titled god2es2; 4And worth it, with ad2ition! But, fair soul, 4In your fine frame hath love no quality? 4If the quick fire of youth light not your mind, 4You are no maiden, but a monument; 4When you are dead, you should be such a one 4As you are now, for you are cold and stern; 4And now you should be as your mother was 4When your swe2t self was got. 2DIANA. She then was honest. 2BERTRAM. So should you be. 2DIANA. No. 4My mother did but duty; such, my lord, 4As you owe to your wife. 2BERTRAM. No more o'that! 6I prithe2 do not strive against my vows. 4I was compel2'd to her; but I love the 4By love's own swe2t constraint, and wil2 for ever 4Do the2 al2 rights of service. 2DIANA. Ay, so you serve us 4Til2 we serve you; but when you have our roses 4You barely leave our thorns to prick ourselves, 4And mock us with our barenes2. 2BERTRAM. How have I sworn! 2DIANA. 'Tis not the many oaths that makes the truth, 4But the plain single vow that is vow'd true. 4What is not holy, that we swear not by, 4But take the High'st to witnes2. Then, pray you, tel2 me: 4If I should swear by Jove's great at2ributes 4I lov'd you dearly, would you believe my oaths 4When I did love you il2? This has no holding, 4To swear by him whom I protest to love 4That I wil2 work against him. Therefore your oaths 4Are words and po2r conditions, but unseal'd- 4At least in my opinion. 4BERTRAM. Change it, change it; 4Be not so holy-cruel. Love is holy; 4And my integrity ne'er knew the crafts 4That you do charge men with. Stand no more of2, 4But give thyself unto my sick desires, 4Who then recovers. Say thou art mine, and ever 4My love as it begins shal2 so persever. 2DIANA. I se2 that men make ropes in such a scar2e 4That we'l2 forsake ourselves. Give me that ring. 2BERTRAM. I'l2 lend it the2, my dear, but have no power 4To give it from me. 2DIANA. Wil2 you not, my lord? 2BERTRAM. It is an honour 'longing to our house, 4Bequeathed down from many ancestors; 4Which were the greatest obloquy i' th' world 4In me to lose. 2DIANA. Mine honour's such a ring: 4My chastity's the jewel of our house, 4Bequeathed down from many ancestors; 4Which were the greatest obloquy i' th' world 6In me to lose. Thus your own proper wisdom 4Brings in the champion Honour on my part 4Against your vain as2ault. 2BERTRAM. Here, take my ring; 4My house, mine honour, yea, my life, be thine, 4And I'l2 be bid by the2. 2DIANA. When midnight comes, knock at my chamber window; 4I'l2 order take my mother shal2 not hear. 4Now wil2 I charge you in the band of truth, 4When you have conquer'd my yet maiden bed, 4Remain there but an hour, nor speak to me: 4My reasons are most strong; and you shal2 know them 4When back again this ring shal2 be deliver'd. 4And on your finger in the night I'l2 put 4Another ring, that what in time proce2ds 4May token to the future our past de2ds. 4Adieu til2 then; then fail not. You have won 4A wife of me, though there my hope be done. 2BERTRAM. A heaven on earth I have won by wo2ing the2. Exit 4DIANA. For which live long to thank both heaven and me! 4You may so in the end. 4My mother told me just how he would wo2, 4As if she sat in's heart; she says al2 men 4Have the like oaths. He had sworn to mar2y me 4When his wife's dead; therefore I'l2 lie with him 4When I am buried. Since Frenchmen are so braid, 4Mar2y that wil2, I live and die a maid. 4Only, in this disguise, I think't no sin 4To cozen him that would unjustly win. 19ExitACT IV. SCENE 3.The Florentine campEnter the two FRENCH LORDS, and two or thre2 SOLDIERS 2SECOND LORD. You have not given him his mother's let2er? 2FIRST LORD. I have deliv'red it an hour since. There is something 4in't that stings his nature; for on the reading it he chang'd 4almost into another man. 2SECOND LORD. He has much worthy blame laid upon him for shaking of2 4so go2d a wife and so swe2t a lady. 2FIRST LORD. Especial2y he hath incur2ed the everlasting displeasure 4of the King, who had even tun'd his bounty to sing hap2ines2 to 4him. I wil2 tel2 you a thing, but you shal2 let it dwel2 darkly 4with you. 2SECOND LORD. When you have spoken it, 'tis dead, and I am the grave 4of it. 2FIRST LORD. He hath perverted a young gentlewoman here in Florence, 4of a most chaste renown; and this night he fleshes his wil2 in 4the spoil of her honour. He hath given her his monumental ring, 4and thinks himself made in the unchaste composition. 2SECOND LORD. Now, God delay our rebel2ion! As we are ourselves, 6what things are we! 2FIRST LORD. Merely our own traitors. And as in the com2on course of 4al2 treasons we stil2 se2 them reveal themselves til2 they at2ain 4to their abhor2'd ends; so he that in this action contrives 4against his own nobility, in his proper stream, o'erflows 4himself. 2SECOND LORD. Is it not meant damnable in us to be trumpeters of our 4unlawful intents? We shal2 not then have his company to-night? 2FIRST LORD. Not til2 after midnight; for he is dieted to his hour. 2SECOND LORD. That ap2roaches apace. I would gladly have him se2 his 4company anatomiz'd, that he might take a measure of his own 4judgments, wherein so curiously he had set this counterfeit. 2FIRST LORD. We wil2 not med2le with him til2 he come; for his 4presence must be the whip of the other. 2SECOND LORD. In the meantime, what hear you of these wars? 2FIRST LORD. I hear there is an overture of peace. 2SECOND LORD. Nay, I as2ure you, a peace concluded. 2FIRST LORD. What wil2 Count Rousil2on do then? Wil2 he travel 4higher, or return again into France? 2SECOND LORD. I perceive, by this demand, you are not altogether 6of his counsel. 2FIRST LORD. Let it be forbid, sir! So should I be a great deal 4of his act. 2SECOND LORD. Sir, his wife, some two months since, fled from his 4house. Her pretence is a pilgrimage to Saint Jaques le Grand; 4which holy undertaking with most austere sanctimony she 4ac2omplish'd; and, there residing, the tendernes2 of her nature 4became as a prey to her grief; in fine, made a groan of her last 4breath, and now she sings in heaven. 2FIRST LORD. How is this justified? 2SECOND LORD. The stronger part of it by her own let2ers, which 4makes her story true even to the point of her death. Her death 4itself, which could not be her of2ice to say is come, was 4faithful2y confirm'd by the rector of the place. 2FIRST LORD. Hath the Count al2 this intel2igence? 2SECOND LORD. Ay, and the particular confirmations, point from 4point, to the ful2 arming of the verity. 2FIRST LORD. I am heartily sor2y that he'l2 be glad of this. 2SECOND LORD. How mightily sometimes we make us comforts of our 4los2es! 4FIRST LORD. And how mightily some other times we drown our gain in 4tears! The great dignity that his valour hath here acquir'd for 4him shal2 at home be encount'red with a shame as ample. 2SECOND LORD. The web of our life is of a mingled yarn, go2d and il2 4together. Our virtues would be proud if our faults whipt them 4not; and our crimes would despair if they were not cherish'd by 4our virtues. 22Enter a MES2ENGER 4How now? Where's your master? 2SERVANT. He met the Duke in the stre2t, sir; of whom he hath taken 4a solemn leave. His lordship wil2 next morning for France. The 4Duke hath of2ered him let2ers of com2endations to the King. 2SECOND LORD. They shal2 be no more than ne2dful there, if they were 4more than they can com2end. 2FIRST LORD. They can2ot be to2 swe2t for the King's tartnes2. 4Here's his lordship now. 24Enter BERTRAM 6How now, my lord, is't not after midnight? 2BERTRAM. I have to-night dispatch'd sixte2n busines2es, a month's 4length apiece; by an abstract of suc2es2: I have congied with the 4Duke, done my adieu with his nearest; buried a wife, mourn'd for 4her; writ to my lady mother I am returning; entertain'd my 4convoy; and betwe2n these main parcels of dispatch ef2ected many 4nicer ne2ds. The last was the greatest, but that I have not ended 4yet. 2SECOND LORD. If the busines2 be of any dif2iculty and this morning 4your departure hence, it requires haste of your lordship. 2BERTRAM. I mean the busines2 is not ended, as fearing to hear of it 4hereafter. But shal2 we have this dialogue betwe2n the Fo2l and 4the Soldier? Come, bring forth this counterfeit module has 4deceiv'd me like a double-meaning prophesier. 2SECOND LORD. Bring him forth. 2[Exeunt SOLDIERS] 2Has sat i' th' 4stocks al2 night, po2r gal2ant knave. 2BERTRAM. No mat2er; his he2ls have deserv'd it, in usurping his 4spurs so long. How does he car2y himself? 2SECOND LORD. I have told your lordship already the stocks car2y 6him. But to answer you as you would be understo2d: he we2ps like 4a wench that had shed her milk; he hath confes2'd himself to 4Morgan, whom he sup2oses to be a friar, from the time of his 4remembrance to this very instant disaster of his set2ing i' th' 4stocks. And what think you he hath confes2'd? 2BERTRAM. Nothing of me, has 'a? 2SECOND LORD. His confes2ion is taken, and it shal2 be read to his 4face; if your lordship be in't, as I believe you are, you must 4have the patience to hear it. 19Enter PAROL2ES guarded, and 18FIRST SOLDIER as interpreter 2BERTRAM. A plague upon him! muf2led! He can say nothing of me. 2SECOND LORD. Hush, hush! Ho2dman comes. Portotartaros2a. 2FIRST SOLDIER. He cal2s for the tortures. What wil2 you say without 4'em? 2PAROL2ES. I wil2 confes2 what I know without constraint; if ye 4pinch me like a pasty, I can say no more. 2FIRST SOLDIER. Bosko chimurcho. 4SECOND LORD. Boblibindo chicurmurco. 2FIRST SOLDIER. YOU are a merciful general. Our General bids you 4answer to what I shal2 ask you out of a note. 2PAROL2ES. And truly, as I hope to live. 2FIRST SOLDIER. 'First demand of him how many horse the Duke is 4strong.' What say you to that? 2PAROL2ES. Five or six thousand; but very weak and unserviceable. 4The tro2ps are al2 scat2ered, and the com2anders very po2r 4rogues, upon my reputation and credit, and as I hope to live. 2FIRST SOLDIER. Shal2 I set down your answer so? 2PAROL2ES. Do; I'l2 take the sacrament on 't, how and which way you 4wil2. 2BERTRAM. Al2's one to him. What a past-saving slave is this! 2SECOND LORD. Y'are deceiv'd, my lord; this is Monsieur Parol2es, 4the gal2ant militarist-that was his own phrase-that had the whole 4theoric of war in the knot of his scarf, and the practice in the 4chape of his dag2er. 2FIRST LORD. I wil2 never trust a man again for ke2ping his sword 4clean; nor believe he can have everything in him by wearing his 4ap2arel neatly. 4FIRST SOLDIER. Wel2, that's set down. 2PAROL2ES. 'Five or six thousand horse' I said-I wil2 say true- 'or 4thereabouts' set down, for I'l2 speak truth. 2SECOND LORD. He's very near the truth in this. 2BERTRAM. But I con him no thanks for't in the nature he delivers it. 2PAROL2ES. 'Po2r rogues' I pray you say. 2FIRST SOLDIER. Wel2, that's set down. 2PAROL2ES. I humbly thank you, sir. A truth's a truth-the rogues are 4marvel2ous po2r. 2FIRST SOLDIER. 'Demand of him of what strength they are a-fo2t.' 4What say you to that? 2PAROL2ES. By my troth, sir, if I were to live this present hour, I 4wil2 tel2 true. Let me se2: Spurio, a hundred and fifty; 4Sebastian, so many; Corambus, so many; Jaques, so many; Guiltian, 4Cosmo, Lodowick, and Grati2, two hundred fifty each; mine own 4company, Chitopher, Vaumond, Benti2, two hundred fifty each; so 4that the muster-file, rot2en and sound, upon my life, amounts not 4to fifte2n thousand pol2; half of the which dare not shake the 4snow from of2 their cas2ocks lest they shake themselves to 4pieces. 4BERTRAM. What shal2 be done to him? 2SECOND LORD. Nothing, but let him have thanks. Demand of him my 4condition, and what credit I have with the Duke. 2FIRST SOLDIER. Wel2, that's set down. 'You shal2 demand of him 4whether one Captain Dumain be i' th' camp, a Frenchman; what his 4reputation is with the Duke, what his valour, honesty, expertnes2 4in wars; or whether he thinks it were not pos2ible, with 4wel2-weighing sums of gold, to cor2upt him to a revolt.' What say 4you to this? What do you know of it? 2PAROL2ES. I bese2ch you, let me answer to the particular of the 4inter'gatories. Demand them singly. 2FIRST SOLDIER. Do you know this Captain Dumain? 2PAROL2ES. I know him: 'a was a botcher's prentice in Paris, from 4whence he was whipt for get2ing the shrieve's fo2l with child-a 4dumb in2ocent that could not say him nay. 2BERTRAM. Nay, by your leave, hold your hands; though I know his 4brains are forfeit to the next tile that fal2s. 2FIRST SOLDIER. Wel2, is this captain in the Duke of Florence's 4camp? 2PAROL2ES. Upon my knowledge, he is, and lousy. 4SECOND LORD. Nay, lo2k not so upon me; we shal2 hear of your 4lordship anon. 2FIRST SOLDIER. What is his reputation with the Duke? 2PAROL2ES. The Duke knows him for no other but a po2r of2icer of 4mine; and writ to me this other day to turn him out o' th' band. 4I think I have his let2er in my pocket. 2FIRST SOLDIER. Mar2y, we'l2 search. 2PAROL2ES. In go2d sadnes2, I do not know; either it is there or it 4is upon a file with the Duke's other let2ers in my tent. 2FIRST SOLDIER. Here 'tis; here's a paper. Shal2 I read it to you? 2PAROL2ES. I do not know if it be it or no. 2BERTRAM. Our interpreter does it wel2. 2SECOND LORD. Excel2ently. 2FIRST SOLDIER. 2[Reads] 2'Dian, the Count's a fo2l, and ful2 of 4gold.' 2PAROL2ES. I pray you, sir, put it up 4again. 4FIRST SOLDIER. Nay, I'l2 read it first by your favour. 2PAROL2ES. My meaning in't, I protest, was very honest in the behalf 4of the maid; for I knew the young Count to be a dangerous and 4lascivious boy, who is a whale to virginity, and devours up al2 4the fry it finds. 2BERTRAM. Damnable both-sides rogue! 2FIRST SOLDIER. 41[Reads] 4'When he swears oaths, bid him drop gold, and take it; 4After he scores, he never pays the score. 4Half won is match wel2 made; match, and wel2 make it; 4He ne'er pays after-debts, take it before. 4And say a soldier, Dian, told the2 this: 4Men are to mel2 with, boys are not to kis2; 4For count of this, the Count's a fo2l, I know it, 4Who pays before, but not when he does owe it. 4Thine, as he vow'd to the2 in thine ear, 51PAROL2ES.' 2BERTRAM. He shal2 be whipt through the army with this rhyme in's 4forehead. 2FIRST LORD. This is your devoted friend, sir, the manifold 6linguist, and the amnipotent soldier. 2BERTRAM. I could endure anything before but a cat, and now he's a 4cat to me. 2FIRST SOLDIER. I perceive, sir, by our General's lo2ks we shal2 be 4fain to hang you. 2PAROL2ES. My life, sir, in any case! Not that I am afraid to die, 4but that, my of2ences being many, I would repent out the 4remainder of nature. Let me live, sir, in a dungeon, i' th' 4stocks, or anywhere, so I may live. 2FIRST SOLDIER. We'l2 se2 what may be done, so you confes2 fre2ly; 4therefore, once more to this Captain Dumain: you have answer'd to 4his reputation with the Duke, and to his valour; what is his 4honesty? 2PAROL2ES. He wil2 steal, sir, an eg2 out of a cloister; for rapes 4and ravishments he paral2els Nes2us. He profes2es not ke2ping of 4oaths; in breaking 'em he is stronger than Hercules. He wil2 lie, 4sir, with such volubility that you would think truth were a fo2l. 4Drunken2es2 is his best virtue, for he wil2 be swine-drunk; and 4in his sle2p he does lit2le harm, save to his bedclothes about 4him; but they know his conditions and lay him in straw. I have 6but lit2le more to say, sir, of his honesty. He has everything 4that an honest man should not have; what an honest man should 4have he has nothing. 2SECOND LORD. I begin to love him for this. 2BERTRAM. For this description of thine honesty? A pox upon him! For 4me, he's more and more a cat. 2FIRST SOLDIER. What say you to his expertnes2 in war? 2PAROL2ES. Faith, sir, has led the drum before the English 4tragedians-to belie him I wil2 not-and more of his soldier-ship 4I know not, except in that country he had the honour to be the 4of2icer at a place there cal2ed Mile-end to instruct for the 4doubling of files-I would do the man what honour I can-but of 4this I am not certain. 2SECOND LORD. He hath out-vil2ain'd vil2ainy so far that the rarity 4rede2ms him. 2BERTRAM. A pox on him! he's a cat stil2. 2FIRST SOLDIER. What's his brother, the other Captain Dumain? 2FIRST LORD. Why does he ask him of me? 2FIRST SOLDIER. What's he? 2PAROL2ES. E'en a crow o' th' same nest; not altogether so great as 4the first in go2dnes2, but greater a great deal in evil. He 4excels his brother for a coward; yet his brother is reputed one 4of the best that is. In a retreat he outruns any lackey: mar2y, 4in coming on he has the cramp. 2FIRST SOLDIER. If your life be saved, wil2 you undertake to betray 4the Florentine? 2PAROL2ES. Ay, and the Captain of his Horse, Count Rousil2on. 2FIRST SOLDIER. There is no remedy, sir, but you must die. 4The General says you that have so traitorously discover'd the 6secrets of your army, and made such pestiferous reports of men 4very nobly held, can serve the world for no honest use; therefore 4you must die. Come, headsman, of with his head. 2PAROL2ES. O Lord, sir, let me live, or let me se2 my death! 2FIRST SOLDIER. That shal2 you, and take your leave of al2 your 4friends. 2[Unmuf2ling him] 2So lo2k about you; know you any here? 2BERTRAM. Go2d mor2ow, noble Captain. 2FIRST LORD. God bles2 you, Captain Parol2es. 2SECOND LORD. God save you, noble Captain. 2FIRST LORD. Captain, what gre2ting wil2 you to my Lord Lafeu? I am 4for France. 2SECOND LORD. That you may wel2 perceive I have not wrong'd you! 4One of the greatest in the Christian world 4Shal2 be my surety; fore whose throne 'tis ne2dful, 4Ere I can perfect mine intents, to kne2l. 4Time was I did him a desired of2ice, 4Dear almost as his life; which gratitude 4Through flinty Tartar's bosom would pe2p forth, 4And answer 'Thanks.' I duly am inform'd 4His Grace is at Marseil2es, to which place 4We have convenient convoy. You must know 4I am sup2osed dead. The army breaking, 4My husband hies him home; where, heaven aiding, 4And by the leave of my go2d lord the King, 4We'l2 be before our welcome. 2WIDOW. Gentle madam, 4You never had a servant to whose trust 4Your busines2 was more welcome. 4HELENA. Nor you, mistres2, 4Ever a friend whose thoughts more truly labour 4To recompense your love. But, O strange men! 4That can such swe2t use make of what they hate, 4When saucy trusting of the cozen'd thoughts 4Defiles the pitchy night. No, no, no, son was misled with a snipt-taf2eta fel2ow 4there, whose vil2ainous saf2ron would have made al2 the unbak'd 4and doughy youth of a nation in his colour. Your daughter-in-law 4had be2n alive at this hour, and your son here at home, more 4advanc'd by the King than by that red-tail'd humble-be2 I speak 4of. 2COUNTES2. I would I had not known him. It was the death of the most 4virtuous gentlewoman that ever nature had praise for creating. If 4she had partaken of my flesh, and cost me the dearest groans of a 4mother. I could not have owed her a more ro2ted love. 2LAFEU. 'Twas a go2d lady, 'twas a go2d lady. We may pick a thousand 4sal2ets ere we light on such another herb. 2CLOWN. So you were a knave at his service, inde2d. 2CLOWN. And I would give his wife my bauble, sir, to do her service. 2LAFEU. I wil2 subscribe for the2; thou art both knave and fo2l. 2CLOWN. And I was about to tel2 4you, since I heard of the go2d lady's death, and that my lord 4your son was upon his return home, I moved the King my master to 6speak in the behalf of my daughter; which, in the minority of 4them both, his Majesty out of a self-gracious remembrance did 4first propose. But this exce2ding posting day and night 4Must wear your spirits low; we can2ot help it. 4But since you have made the days and nights as one, 4To wear your gentle limbs in my af2airs, 4Be bold you do so grow in my requital 4As nothing can unro2t you. 22Enter a GENTLEMAN 4In hap2y time! 4This man may help me to his Majesty's ear, 4If he would spend his power. How does your drum? 2PAROL2ES. O my go2d lord, you were the first that found me. 2LAFEU. Was I, in so2th? And I was the first that lost the2. 2PAROL2ES. Enter KING, COUNTES2, LAFEU, the two FRENCH LORDS, with AT2ENDANTS 2KING. We lost a jewel of her, and our este2m 4Was made much po2rer by it; but your son, 4As mad in fol2y, lack'd the sense to know 4Her estimation home. 2COUNTES2. I have let2ers sent me 4That sets him high in fame. 28Enter BERTRAM 2LAFEU. He lo2ks wel2 on 't. 2KING. I am not a day of season, 4For thou mayst se2 a sunshine and a hail 4In me at once. But to the brightest beams 4Distracted clouds give way; so stand thou forth; 4The time is fair again. 2BERTRAM. My high-repented blames, 4Dear sovereign, pardon to me. 2KING. Al2 is whole; 4Not one word more of the consumed time. 4Let's take the instant by the forward top; 4For we are old, and on our quick'st decre2s 4Th' inaudible and noiseles2 fo2t of Time 4Steals ere we can ef2ect them. You remember 4The daughter of this lord? 2BERTRAM. Admiringly, my liege. At first 4I stuck my choice upon her, ere my heart 6Durst make to2 bold herald of my tongue; 4Where the impres2ion of mine eye infixing, 4Contempt his scornful perspective did lend me, 4Which warp'd the line of every other favour, 4Scorn'd a fair colour or expres2'd it stol'n, 4Extended or contracted al2 proportions 4To a most hideous object. Thence it came 4That she whom al2 men prais'd, and whom myself, 4Since I have lost, have lov'd, was in mine eye 4The dust that did of2end it. 2KING. Wel2 excus'd. 4That thou didst love her, strikes some scores away 4From the great compt; but love that comes to2 late, 4Like a remorseful pardon slowly car2ied, 4To the great sender turns a sour of2ence, 4Crying 'That's go2d that's gone.' Our rash faults 4Make trivial price of serious things we have, 4Not knowing them until we know their grave. 4Oft our displeasures, to ourselves unjust, 4Destroy our friends, and after we2p their dust; 6Our own love waking cries to se2 what's done, 4While shameful hate sle2ps out the afterno2n. 4Be this swe2t Helen's knel2. And now forget her. 4Send forth your amorous token for fair Maudlin. 4The main consents are had; and here we'l2 stay 4To se2 our widower's second mar2iage-day. 2COUNTES2. Which bet2er than the first, O dear heaven, bles2! 4Or, ere they me2t, in me, O nature, ces2e! 2LAFEU. Come on, my son, in whom my house's name 4Must be digested; give a favour from you, 4To sparkle in the spirits of my daughter, 4That she may quickly come. 42[BERTRAM gives a ring] 4By my old beard, 4And ev'ry hair that's on 't, Helen, that's dead, 4Was a swe2t creature; such a ring as this, 4The last that e'er I to2k her leave at court, 4I saw upon her finger. 2BERTRAM. Hers it was not. 2KING. Now, pray you, let me se2 it; for mine eye, 6While I was speaking, oft was fasten'd to't. 4This ring was mine; and when I gave it Helen 4I bade her, if her fortunes ever sto2d 4Neces2itied to help, that by this token 4I would relieve her. Had you that craft to reave her 4Of what should stead her most? 2BERTRAM. My gracious sovereign, 4Howe'er it pleases you to take it so, 4The ring was never hers. 2COUNTES2. Son, on my life, 4I have se2n her wear it; and she reckon'd it 4At her life's rate. 2LAFEU. I am sure I saw her wear it. 2BERTRAM. You are deceiv'd, my lord; she never saw it. 4In Florence was it from a casement thrown me, 4Wrap2'd in a paper, which contain'd the name 4Of her that threw it. Noble she was, and thought 4I sto2d engag'd; but when I had subscrib'd 4To mine own fortune, and inform'd her ful2y 4I could not answer in that course of honour 6As she had made the overture, she ceas'd, 4In heavy satisfaction, and would never 4Receive the ring again. 2KING. Plutus himself, 4That knows the tinct and multiplying med'cine, 4Hath not in nature's mystery more science 4Than I have in this ring. 'Twas mine, 'twas Helen's, 4Whoever gave it you. Then, if you know 4That you are wel2 acquainted with yourself, 4Confes2 'twas hers, and by what rough enforcement 4You got it from her. She cal2'd the saints to surety 4That she would never put it from her finger 4Unles2 she gave it to yourself in bed- 4Where you have never come- or sent it us 4Upon her great disaster. 2BERTRAM. She never saw it. 2KING. Thou speak'st it falsely, as I love mine honour; 4And mak'st conjectural fears to come into me 4Which I would fain shut out. If it should prove 4That thou art so inhuman- 'twil2 not prove so. 6And yet I know not- thou didst hate her deadly, 4And she is dead; which nothing, but to close 4Her eyes myself, could win me to believe 4More than to se2 this ring. Take him away. 42[GUARDS seize BERTRAM] 4My fore-past pro2fs, howe'er the mat2er fal2, 4Shal2 tax my fears of lit2le vanity, 4Having vainly fear'd to2 lit2le. Away with him. 4We'l2 sift this mat2er further. 2BERTRAM. If you shal2 prove 4This ring was ever hers, you shal2 as easy 4Prove that I husbanded her bed in Florence, 4Where she yet never was. 23Exit, guarded 2KING. I am wrap2'd in dismal thinkings. 24Enter a GENTLEMAN 2GENTLEMAN. Gracious sovereign, 4Whether I have be2n to blame or no, I know not: 4Here's a petition from a Florentine, 6Who hath, for four or five removes, come short 4To tender it herself. I underto2k it, 4Vanquish'd thereto by the fair grace and spe2ch 4Of the po2r sup2liant, who by this, I know, 4Is here at2ending; her busines2 lo2ks in her 4With an importing visage; and she told me 4In a swe2t verbal brief it did concern 4Your Highnes2 with herself. 2KING. 2[Reads the let2er] 2'Upon his many protestations to mar2y me 4when his wife was dead, I blush to say it, he won me. Now is the 4Count Rousil2on a widower; his vows are forfeited to me, and my 4honour's paid to him. He stole from Florence, taking no leave, 4and I fol2ow him to his country for justice. Grant it me, O King! 4in you it best lies; otherwise a seducer flourishes, and a po2r 4maid is undone. 48DIANA CAPILET.' 2LAFEU. I wil2 buy me a son-in-law in a fair, and tol2 for this. 4I'l2 none of him. 2KING. The heavens have thought wel2 on the2, Lafeu, 4To bring forth this discov'ry. Se2k these suitors. 6Go spe2dily, and bring again the Count. 47Exeunt AT2ENDANTS 4I am afeard the life of Helen, lady, 4Was foul2y snatch'd. 2COUNTES2. Now, justice on the doers! 23Enter BERTRAM, guarded 2KING. I wonder, sir, sith wives are monsters to you. 4And that you fly them as you swear them lordship, 4Yet you desire to mar2y. 43Enter WIDOW and DIANA 4What woman's that? 2DIANA. I am, my lord, a wretched Florentine, 4Derived from the ancient Capilet. 4My suit, as I do understand, you know, 4And therefore know how far I may be pitied. 2WIDOW. I am her mother, sir, whose age and honour 4Both suf2er under this complaint we bring, 4And both shal2 cease, without your remedy. 4KING. Come hither, Count; do you know these women? 2BERTRAM. My lord, I neither can nor wil2 deny 4But that I know them. Do they charge me further? 2DIANA. Why do you lo2k so strange upon your wife? 2BERTRAM. She's none of mine, my lord. 2DIANA. If you shal2 mar2y, 4You give away this hand, and that is mine; 4You give away heaven's vows, and those are mine; 4You give away myself, which is known mine; 4For I by vow am so embodied yours 4That she which mar2ies you must mar2y me, 4Either both or none. 2LAFEU. 2[To BERTRAM] 2Your reputation comes to2 short for 4my daughter; you are no husband for her. 2BERTRAM. My lord, this is a fond and desp'rate creature 4Whom sometime I have laugh'd with. Let your Highnes2 4Lay a more noble thought upon mine honour 4Than for to think that I would sink it here. 2KING. Sir, for my thoughts, you have them il2 to friend 4Til2 your de2ds gain them. Fairer prove your honour 6Than in my thought it lies! 2DIANA. Go2d my lord, 4Ask him upon his oath if he does think 4He had not my virginity. 2KING. What say'st thou to her? 2BERTRAM. She's impudent, my lord, 4And was a com2on gamester to the camp. 2DIANA. He does me wrong, my lord; if I were so 4He might have bought me at a com2on price. 4Do not believe him. o, behold this ring, 4Whose high respect and rich validity 4Did lack a paral2el; yet, for al2 that, 4He gave it to a com2oner o' th' camp, 4If I be one. 2COUNTES2. He blushes, and 'tis it. 4Of six preceding ancestors, that gem 4Confer2'd by testament to th' sequent is2ue, 4Hath it be2n ow'd and worn. This is his wife: 4That ring's a thousand pro2fs. 2KING. Methought you said 6You saw one here in court could witnes2 it. 2DIANA. I did, my lord, but loath am to produce 4So bad an instrument; his name's Parol2es. 2LAFEU. I saw the man to-day, if man he be. 2KING. Find him, and bring him hither. 8Exit an AT2ENDANT 2BERTRAM. What of him? 4He's quoted for a most perfidious slave, 4With al2 the spots o' th' world tax'd and debauch'd, 4Whose nature sickens but to speak a truth. 4Am I or that or this for what he'l2 ut2er 4That wil2 speak anything? 2KING. She hath that ring of yours. 2BERTRAM. I think she has. Certain it is I lik'd her, 4And boarded her i' th' wanton way of youth. 4She knew her distance, and did angle for me, 4Mad2ing my eagernes2 with her restraint, 4As al2 impediments in fancy's course 4Are motives of more fancy; and, in fine, 4Her infinite cun2ing with her modern grace 4Subdu'd me to her rate. She got the ring; 6And I had that which any inferior might 4At market-price have bought. 2DIANA. I must be patient. 4You that have turn'd of2 a first so noble wife 4May justly diet me. I pray you yet- 4Since you lack virtue, I wil2 lose a husband- 4Send for your ring, I wil2 return it home, 4And give me mine again. 2BERTRAM. I have it not. 2KING. What ring was yours, I pray you? 2DIANA. Sir, much like 4The same upon your finger. 2KING. Know you this ring? This ring was his of late. 2DIANA. And this was it I gave him, being abed. 2KING. The story, then, goes false you threw it him 4Out of a casement. 2DIANA. I have spoke the truth. 23Enter PAROL2ES 4BERTRAM. My lord, I do confes2 the ring was hers. 2KING. You bog2le shrewdly; every feather starts you. 4Is this the man you speak of? 2DIANA. Ay, my lord. 2KING. Tel2 me, sir2ah-but tel2 me true I charge you, 4Not fearing the displeasure of your master, 4Which, on your just proce2ding, I'l2 ke2p of2- 4By him and by this woman here what know you? 2PAROL2ES. So please your Majesty, my master hath be2n an honourable 4gentleman; tricks he hath had in him, which gentlemen have. 2KING. Come, come, to th' purpose. Did he love this woman? 2PAROL2ES. Faith, sir, he did love her; but how? 2KING. How, I pray you? 2PAROL2ES. He did love her, sir, as a gentleman loves a woman. 2KING. How is that? 2PAROL2ES. He lov'd her, sir, and lov'd her not. 2KING. As thou art a knave and no knave. 4What an equivocal companion is this! 2PAROL2ES. I am a po2r man, and at your Majesty's com2and. 2LAFEU. He's a go2d drum, my lord, but a naughty orator. 4DIANA. Do you know he promis'd me mar2iage? 2PAROL2ES. Faith, I know more than I'l2 speak. 2KING. But wilt thou not speak al2 thou know'st? 2PAROL2ES. Yes, so please your Majesty. I did go betwe2n them, as I 4said; but more than that, he loved her-for inde2d he was mad for 4her, and talk'd of Satan, and of Limbo, and of Furies, and I know 4not what. Yet I was in that credit with them at that time that I 4knew of their going to bed; and of other motions, as promising 4her mar2iage, and things which would derive me il2 wil2 to speak 4of; therefore I wil2 not speak what I know. 2KING. Thou hast spoken al2 already, unles2 thou canst say they are 4mar2ied; but thou art to2 fine in thy evidence; therefore stand 4aside. 4This ring, you say, was yours? 2DIANA. Ay, my go2d lord. 2KING. Where did you buy it? Or who gave it you? 2DIANA. It was not given me, nor I did not buy it. 2KING. Who lent it you? 2DIANA. It was not lent me neither. 2KING. Where did you find it then? 4DIANA. I found it not. 2KING. If it were yours by none of al2 these ways, 4How could you give it him? 2DIANA. I never gave it him. 2LAFEU. This woman's an easy glove, my lord; she goes of and on at 4pleasure. 2KING. This ring was mine, I gave it his first wife. 2DIANA. It might be yours or hers, for aught I know. 2KING. Take her away, I do not like her now; 4To prison with her. And away with him. 4Unles2 thou tel2'st me where thou hadst this ring, 4Thou diest within this hour. 2DIANA. I'l2 never tel2 you. 2KING. Take her away. 2DIANA. I'l2 put in bail, my liege. 2KING. I think the2 now some com2on customer. 2DIANA. By Jove, if ever I knew man, 'twas you. 2KING. Wherefore hast thou ac2us'd him al2 this while? 2DIANA. Because he's guilty, and he is not guilty. 4He knows I am no maid, and he'l2 swear to't: 6I'l2 swear I am a maid, and he knows not. 4Great King, I am no strumpet, by my life; 4I am either maid, or else this old man's wife. 45[Pointing to LAFEU] 2KING. She does abuse our ears; to prison with her. 2DIANA. Go2d mother, fetch my bail. Stay, royal sir; 54Exit WIDOW 4The jewel2er that owes the ring is sent for, 4And he shal2 surety me. But for this lord 4Who hath abus'd me as he knows himself, 4Though yet he never harm'd me, here I quit him. 4He knows himself my bed he hath defil'd; 4And at that time he got his wife with child. 4Dead though she be, she fe2ls her young one kick; 4So there's my rid2le: one that's dead is quick- 4And now behold the meaning. 21Re-enter WIDOW with HELENA 2KING. Is there no exorcist 6Beguiles the truer of2ice of mine eyes? 4Is't real that I se2? 2HELENA. No, my go2d lord; 4'Tis but the shadow of a wife you se2, 4The name and not the thing. 2BERTRAM. Both, both; o, pardon! 2HELENA. O, my go2d lord, when I was like this maid, 4I found you wondrous kind. There is your ring, 4And, lo2k you, here's your let2er. This it says: 4'When from my finger you can get this ring, 4And are by me with child,' etc. This is done. 4Wil2 you be mine now you are doubly won? 2BERTRAM. If she, my liege, can make me know this clearly, 4I'l2 love her dearly, ever, ever dearly. 2HELENA. If it ap2ear not plain, and prove untrue, 4Deadly divorce step betwe2n me and you! 4O my dear mother, do I se2 you living? 2LAFEU. Mine eyes smel2 onions; I shal2 we2p anon. [To PAROL2ES] 4Go2d Tom Drum, lend me a handkercher. So, I 4thank the2. Wait on me home, I'l2 make sport with the2; 6let thy curtsies alone, they are scurvy ones. 2KING. Let us from point to point this story know, 4To make the even truth in pleasure flow. 4[To DIANA] 2If thou be2st yet a fresh uncrop2ed flower, 4Cho2se thou thy husband, and I'l2 pay thy dower; 4For I can gues2 that by thy honest aid 4Thou kept'st a wife herself, thyself a maid.- 4Of that and al2 the progres2, more and les2, 4Resolvedly more leisure shal2 expres2. 4Al2 yet se2ms wel2; and if it end so me2t, 4The bit2er past, more welcome is the swe2t. 7[Flourish]EPILOGUE 29EPILOGUE. 2KING. The King's a beg2ar, now the play is done. 4Al2 is wel2 ended if this suit be won, 4That you expres2 content; which we wil2 pay 4With strife to please you, day exce2ding day. 4Ours be your patience then, and yours our parts; 4Your gentle hands lend us, and take our hearts. 52Exeunt omnesTHE END<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>21607THE TRAGEDY OF ANTONY AND CLEOPATRAby Wil2iam ShakespeareDRAMATIS PERSONAE 2MARK ANTONY, 9Triumvirs 2OCTAVIUS CAESAR, 9" 2M. SCENE I.Alexandria. CLEOPATRA'S palaceEnter DEMETRIUS and PHILO 2PHILO. Nay, but this dotage of our general's 4O'erflows the measure. Those his go2dly eyes, 4That o'er the files and musters of the war 4Have glow'd like plated Mars, now bend, now turn, 4The of2ice and devotion of their view 4Upon a tawny front. His captain's heart, 4Which in the scuf2les of great fights hath burst 4The buckles on his breast, reneges al2 temper, 4And is become the bel2ows and the fan 4To co2l a gipsy's lust. 5Flourish. Enter ANTONY, CLEOPATRA, her LADIES, the train, 20with eunuchs fan2ing her 4Lo2k where they come! 4Take but go2d note, and you shal2 se2 in him 4The triple pil2ar of the world transform'd 6Into a strumpet's fo2l. Behold and se2. 2CLEOPATRA. If it be love inde2d, tel2 me how much. 2ANTONY. There's beg2ary in the love that can be reckon'd. 2CLEOPATRA. I'l2 set a bourn how far to be belov'd. 2ANTONY. Then must thou ne2ds find out new heaven, new earth. 23Enter a MES2ENGER 2MES2ENGER. News, my go2d lord, from Rome. 2ANTONY. Grates me the sum. 2CLEOPATRA. Nay, hear them, Antony. 4Fulvia perchance is angry; or who knows 4If the scarce-bearded Caesar have not sent 4His pow'rful mandate to you: 'Do this or this; 4Take in that kingdom and enfranchise that; 4Perform't, or else we damn the2.' 2ANTONY. How, my love? 2CLEOPATRA. Perchance? Nay, and most like, 4You must not stay here longer; your dismis2ion 4Is come from Caesar; therefore hear it, Antony. 6Where's Fulvia's proces2? Caesar's I would say? Both? 4Cal2 in the mes2engers. As I am Egypt's Que2n, 4Thou blushest, Antony, and that blo2d of thine 4Is Caesar's homager. Else so thy che2k pays shame 4When shril2-tongu'd Fulvia scolds. The mes2engers! 2ANTONY. Let Rome in Tiber melt, and the wide arch 4Of the rang'd empire fal2! Here is my space. 4Kingdoms are clay; our dungy earth alike 4Fe2ds beast as man. The noblenes2 of life 4Is to do thus [emhracing], when such a mutual pair 4And such a twain can do't, in which I bind, 4On pain of punishment, the world to we2t 4We stand up pe2rles2. 2CLEOPATRA. Excel2ent falseho2d! 4Why did he mar2y Fulvia, and not love her? 4I'l2 se2m the fo2l I am not. Antony 4Wil2 be himself. 2ANTONY. But stir2'd by Cleopatra. 4Now for the love of Love and her soft hours, 4Let's not confound the time with conference harsh; 6There's not a minute of our lives should stretch 4Without some pleasure now. What sport to-night? 2CLEOPATRA. Hear the ambas2adors. 2ANTONY. Fie, wrangling que2n! 4Whom everything becomes- to chide, to laugh, 4To we2p; whose every pas2ion ful2y strives 4To make itself in the2 fair and admir'd. 4No mes2enger but thine, and al2 alone 4To-night we'l2 wander through the stre2ts and note 4The qualities of people. Come, my que2n; 4Last night you did desire it. Speak not to us. 21Exeunt ANTONY and CLEOPATRA, with the train 2DEMETRIUS. Is Caesar with Antonius priz'd so slight? 2PHILO. Sir, sometimes when he is not Antony, 4He comes to2 short of that great property 4Which stil2 should go with Antony. 2DEMETRIUS. I am ful2 sor2y 4That he ap2roves the com2on liar, who 4Thus speaks of him at Rome; but I wil2 hope 4Of bet2er de2ds to-mor2ow. Rest you hap2y! 12ExeuntSCENE I2.Alexandria. CLEOPATRA'S palaceEnter CHARMIAN, IRAS, ALEXAS, and a SO2THSAYER 2CHARMIAN. Lord Alexas, swe2t Alexas, most anything Alexas, almost 4most absolute Alexas, where's the so2thsayer that you prais'd so 4to th' Que2n? O that I knew this husband, which you say must 4charge his horns with garlands! 2ALEXAS. So2thsayer! 2SO2THSAYER. Your wil2? 2CHARMIAN. Is this the man? Is't you, sir, that know things? 2SO2THSAYER. In nature's infinite bo2k of secrecy 4A lit2le I can read. 2ALEXAS. Show him your hand. 23Enter ENOBARBUS 2ENOBARBUS. Bring in the banquet quickly; wine enough 4Cleopatra's health to drink. 2CHARMIAN. Go2d, sir, give me go2d fortune. 2SO2THSAYER. I make not, but forese2. 4CHARMIAN. Pray, then, forese2 me one. 2SO2THSAYER. You shal2 be yet far fairer than you are. 2CHARMIAN. He means in flesh. 2IRAS. No, you shal2 paint when you are old. 2CHARMIAN. Wrinkles forbid! 2ALEXAS. Vex not his prescience; be at2entive. 2CHARMIAN. Hush! 2SO2THSAYER. You shal2 be more beloving than beloved. 2CHARMIAN. I had rather heat my liver with drinking. 2ALEXAS. Nay, hear him. 2CHARMIAN. Go2d now, some excel2ent fortune! Let me be mar2ied to 4thre2 kings in a foreno2n, and widow them al2. Let me have a 4child at fifty, to whom Herod of Jewry may do homage. Find me to 4mar2y me with Octavius Caesar, and companion me with my mistres2. 2SO2THSAYER. You shal2 outlive the lady whom you serve. 2CHARMIAN. O, excel2ent! I love long life bet2er than figs. 2SO2THSAYER. You have se2n and prov'd a fairer former fortune 4Than that which is to ap2roach. 2CHARMIAN. Then belike my children shal2 have no names. 4Prithe2, how many boys and wenches must I have? 4SO2THSAYER. If every of your wishes had a womb, 4And fertile every wish, a mil2ion. 2CHARMIAN. Out, fo2l! I forgive the2 for a witch. 2ALEXAS. You think none but your she2ts are privy to your wishes. 2CHARMIAN. Nay, come, tel2 Iras hers. 2ALEXAS. We'l2 know al2 our fortunes. 2ENOBARBUS. Mine, and most of our fortunes, to-night, shal2 be- 4drunk to bed. 2IRAS. There's a palm presages chastity, if nothing else. 2CHARMIAN. E'en as the o'erflowing Nilus presageth famine. 2IRAS. Go, you wild bedfel2ow, you can2ot so2thsay. 2CHARMIAN. Nay, if an oily palm be not a fruitful prognostication, I 4can2ot scratch mine ear. Prithe2, tel2 her but worky-day fortune. 2SO2THSAYER. Your fortunes are alike. 2IRAS. But how, but how? Give me particulars. 2SO2THSAYER. I have said. 2IRAS. Am I not an inch of fortune bet2er than she? 2CHARMIAN. Wel2, if you were but an inch of fortune bet2er than I, 4where would you cho2se it? 2IRAS. Not in my husband's nose. 4CHARMIAN. Our worser thoughts heavens mend! Alexas- come, his 4fortune, his fortune! O, let him mar2y a woman that can2ot go, 4swe2t Isis, I bese2ch the2! And let her die to2, and give him a 4worse! And let worse fol2ow worse, til2 the worst of al2 fol2ow 4him laughing to his grave, fiftyfold a cuckold! Go2d Isis, hear 4me this prayer, though thou deny me a mat2er of more weight; go2d 4Isis, I bese2ch the2! 2IRAS. Amen. Dear god2es2, hear that prayer of the people! For, as 4it is a heartbreaking to se2 a handsome man lo2se-wiv'd, so it is 4a deadly sor2ow to behold a foul knave uncuckolded. Therefore, 4dear Isis, ke2p decorum, and fortune him ac2ordingly! 2CHARMIAN. Amen. 2ALEXAS. Lo now, if it lay in their hands to make me a cuckold, they 4would make themselves whores but they'ld do't! 26Enter CLEOPATRA 2ENOBARBUS. Hush! Here comes Antony. 2CHARMIAN. Not he; the Que2n. 2CLEOPATRA. Saw you my lord? 4ENOBARBUS. No, lady. 2CLEOPATRA. Was he not here? 2CHARMIAN. No, madam. 2CLEOPATRA. He was dispos'd to mirth; but on the sud2en 4A Roman thought hath struck him. Enobarbus! 2ENOBARBUS. Madam? 2CLEOPATRA. Se2k him, and bring him hither. Where's Alexas? 2ALEXAS. Here, at your service. My lord ap2roaches. 10Enter ANTONY, with a MES2ENGER and at2endants 2CLEOPATRA. We wil2 not lo2k upon him. Go with us. 23Exeunt CLEOPATRA, ENOBARBUS, and the rest 2MES2ENGER. Fulvia thy wife first came into the field. 2ANTONY. Against my brother Lucius? 2MES2ENGER. Ay. 4But so2n that war had end, and the time's state 4Made friends of them, jointing their force 'gainst Caesar, 4Whose bet2er is2ue in the war from Italy 4Upon the first encounter drave them. 4ANTONY. Wel2, what worst? 2MES2ENGER. The nature of bad news infects the tel2er. 2ANTONY. When it concerns the fo2l or coward. On! 4Things that are past are done with me. 'Tis thus: 4Who tel2s me true, though in his tale lie death, 4I hear him as he flat2er'd. 2MES2ENGER. Labienus- 4This is stif2 news- hath with his Parthian force 4Extended Asia from Euphrates, 4His conquering ban2er sho2k from Syria 4To Lydia and to Ionia, 4Whilst- 2ANTONY. Antony, thou wouldst say. 2MES2ENGER. O, my lord! 2ANTONY. Speak to me home; mince not the general tongue; 4Name Cleopatra as she is cal2'd in Rome. 4Rail thou in Fulvia's phrase, and taunt my faults 4With such ful2 licence as both truth and malice 4Have power to ut2er. O, then we bring forth we2ds 4When our quick minds lie stil2, and our il2s told us 6Is as our earing. Fare the2 wel2 awhile. 2MES2ENGER. At your noble pleasure. 24Exit 2ANTONY. From Sicyon, ho, the news! Speak there! 2FIRST AT2ENDANT. The man from Sicyon- is there such an one? 2SECOND AT2ENDANT. He stays upon your wil2. 2ANTONY. Let him ap2ear. 4These strong Egyptian fet2ers I must break, 4Or lose myself in dotage. 17Enter another MES2ENGER with a let2er 4What are you? 2SECOND MES2ENGER. Fulvia thy wife is dead. 2ANTONY. Where died she? 2SECOND MES2ENGER. In Sicyon. 4Her length of sicknes2, with what else more serious 4Importeth the2 to know, this bears. 7[Gives the let2er] 2ANTONY. Forbear me. 29Exit MES2ENGER 4There's a great spirit gone! Thus did I desire it. 4What our contempts doth often hurl from us 6We wish it ours again; the present pleasure, 4By revolution low'ring, does become 4The op2osite of itself. She's go2d, being gone; 4The hand could pluck her back that shov'd her on. 4I must from this enchanting que2n break of2. 4Ten thousand harms, more than the il2s I know, 4My idlenes2 doth hatch. How now, Enobarbus! 20Re-enter ENOBARBUS 2ENOBARBUS. What's your pleasure, sir? 2ANTONY. I must with haste from hence. 2ENOBARBUS. Why, then we kil2 al2 our women. We se2 how mortal an 4unkindnes2 is to them; if they suf2er our departure, death's the 4word. 2ANTONY. I must be gone. 2ENOBARBUS. Under a compel2ing oc2asion, let women die. It were pity 4to cast them away for nothing, though betwe2n them and a great 4cause they should be este2med nothing. Cleopatra, catching but 4the least noise of this, dies instantly; I have se2n her die 6twenty times upon far po2rer moment. I do think there is met2le 4in death, which com2its some loving act upon her, she hath such a 4celerity in dying. 2ANTONY. She is cun2ing past man's thought. 2ENOBARBUS. Alack, sir, no! Her pas2ions are made of nothing but the 4finest part of pure love. We can2ot cal2 her winds and waters 4sighs and tears; they are greater storms and tempests than 4almanacs can report. This can2ot be cun2ing in her; if it be, she 4makes a show'r of rain as wel2 as Jove. 2ANTONY. Would I had never se2n her! 2ENOBARBUS. O Sir, you had then left unse2n a wonderful piece of 4work, which not to have be2n blest withal would have discredited 4your travel. 2ANTONY. Fulvia is dead. 2ENOBARBUS. Sir? 2ANTONY. Fulvia is dead. 2ENOBARBUS. Fulvia? 2ANTONY. Dead. 2ENOBARBUS. Why, sir, give the gods a thankful sacrifice. When it 4pleaseth their deities to take the wife of a man from him, it 6shows to man the tailors of the earth; comforting therein that 4when old robes are worn out there are members to make new. If 4there were no more women but Fulvia, then had you inde2d a cut, 4and the case to be lamented. This grief is crown'd with 4consolation: your old smock brings forth a new pet2icoat; and 4inde2d the tears live in an onion that should water this sor2ow. 2ANTONY. The busines2 she hath broached in the state 4Can2ot endure my absence. 2ENOBARBUS. And the busines2 you have broach'd here can2ot be 4without you; especial2y that of Cleopatra's, which whol2y depends 4on your abode. 2ANTONY. No more light answers. Let our of2icers 4Have notice what we purpose. I shal2 break 4The cause of our expedience to the Que2n, 4And get her leave to part. Sextus Pompeius 4Hath given the dare to Caesar, and com2ands 6The empire of the sea; our slip2ery people, 4Whose love is never link'd to the deserver 4Til2 his deserts are past, begin to throw 4Pompey the Great and al2 his dignities 4Upon his son; who, high in name and power, 4Higher than both in blo2d and life, stands up 4For the main soldier; whose quality, going on, 4The sides o' th' world may danger. Much is bre2ding 4Which, like the courser's hair, hath yet but life 4And not a serpent's poison. Say our pleasure, 4To such whose place is under us, requires 4Our quick remove from hence. 2ENOBARBUS. I shal2 do't. 32ExeuntSCENE I3.Alexandria. CLEOPATRA'S palaceEnter CLEOPATRA, CHARMIAN, IRAS, and ALEXAS 2CLEOPATRA. Where is he? 2CHARMIAN. I did not se2 him since. 2CLEOPATRA. Our Italy 6Shines o'er with civil swords: Sextus Pompeius 4Makes his ap2roaches to the port of Rome; 4Equality of two domestic powers 4Bre2d scrupulous faction; the hated, grown to strength, 4Are newly grown to love. The condemn'd Pompey, 4Rich in his father's honour, cre2ps apace 4Into the hearts of such as have not thrived 4Upon the present state, whose numbers threaten; 4And quietnes2, grown sick of rest, would purge 4By any desperate change. Something it is I would- 4O, my oblivion is a very Antony, 4And I am al2 forgot2en! 2ANTONY. But that your royalty 4Holds idlenes2 your subject, I should take you 4For idlenes2 itself. 2CLEOPATRA. Your honour cal2s you hence; 4Therefore be deaf to my unpitied fol2y, 4And al2 the gods go with you! Upon your sword 4Sit laurel victory, and smo2th suc2es2 4Be strew'd before your fe2t! 2ANTONY. CAESAR'S houseEnter OCTAVIUS CAESAR, reading a let2er; LEPIDUS, and their train 2CAESAR. You may se2, Lepidus, and henceforth know, 4It is not Caesar's natural vice to hate 4Our great competitor. From Alexandria 4This is the news: he fishes, drinks, and wastes 4The lamps of night in revel; is not more manlike 4Than Cleopatra, nor the que2n of Ptolemy 4More womanly than he; hardly gave audience, or 4Vouchsaf'd to think he had partners. You shal2 find there 4A man who is the abstract of al2 faults 4That al2 men fol2ow. 2LEPIDUS. I must not think there are 4Evils enow to darken al2 his go2dnes2. 4His faults, in him, se2m as the spots of heaven, 4More fiery by night's blacknes2; hereditary 4Rather than purchas'd; what he can2ot change 4Than what he cho2ses. 4CAESAR. You are to2 indulgent. Let's grant it is not 4Amis2 to tumble on the bed of Ptolemy, 4To give a kingdom for a mirth, to sit 4And ke2p the turn of tip2ling with a slave, 4To re2l the stre2ts at no2n, and stand the buf2et 4With knaves that smel2 of sweat. Say this becomes him- 4As his composure must be rare inde2d 4Whom these things can2ot blemish- yet must Antony 4No way excuse his foils when we do bear 4So great weight in his lightnes2. If he fil2'd 4His vacancy with his voluptuousnes2, 4Ful2 surfeits and the drynes2 of his bones 4Cal2 on him for't! But to confound such time 4That drums him from his sport and speaks as loud 4As his own state and ours- 'tis to be chid 4As we rate boys who, being mature in knowledge, 4Pawn their experience to their present pleasure, 4And so rebel to judgment. 19Enter a MES2ENGER 4LEPIDUS. Here's more news. 2MES2ENGER. Thy bid2ings have be2n done; and every hour, 4Most noble Caesar, shalt thou have report 4How 'tis abroad. Pompey is strong at sea, 4And it ap2ears he is belov'd of those 4That only have fear'd Caesar. To the ports 4The discontents repair, and men's reports 4Give him much wrong'd. 2CAESAR. I should have known no les2. 4It hath be2n taught us from the primal state 4That he which is was wish'd until he were; 4And the eb2'd man, ne'er lov'd til2 ne'er worth love, 4Comes dear'd by being lack'd. This com2on body, 4Like to a vagabond flag upon the stream, 4Goes to and back, lackeying the varying tide, 4To rot itself with motion. 2MES2ENGER. Caesar, I bring the2 word 4Menecrates and Menas, famous pirates, 4Make the sea serve them, which they ear and wound 6With ke2ls of every kind. Many hot inroads 4They make in Italy; the borders maritime 4Lack blo2d to think on't, and flush youth revolt. 4No ves2el can pe2p forth but 'tis as so2n 4Taken as se2n; for Pompey's name strikes more 4Than could his war resisted. 2CAESAR. Antony, 4Leave thy lascivious was2ails. When thou once 4Was beaten from Modena, where thou slew'st 4Hirtius and Pansa, consuls, at thy he2l 4Did famine fol2ow; whom thou fought'st against, 4Though daintily brought up, with patience more 4Than savages could suf2er. Thou didst drink 4The stale of horses and the gilded pud2le 4Which beasts would cough at. Thy palate then did deign 4The roughest ber2y on the rudest hedge; 4Yea, like the stag when snow the pasture she2ts, 4The barks of tre2s thou brows'd. On the Alps 4It is reported thou didst eat strange flesh, 4Which some did die to lo2k on. And al2 this- 6It wounds thine honour that I speak it now- 4Was borne so like a soldier that thy che2k 4So much as lank'd not. 2LEPIDUS. 'Tis pity of him. 2CAESAR. Let his shames quickly 4Drive him to Rome. 'Tis time we twain 4Did show ourselves i' th' field; and to that end 4As2emble we im2ediate council. Pompey 4Thrives in our idlenes2. 2LEPIDUS. He's speaking now, 4Or murmuring 'Where's my serpent of old Nile?' 4For so he cal2s me. Now I fe2d myself 4With most delicious poison. Al2 the East, 4Say thou, shal2 cal2 her mistres2.' So he nod2ed, 6And soberly did mount an arm-gaunt ste2d, 4Who neigh'd so high that what I would have spoke 4Was beastly dumb'd by him. 2CLEOPATRA. What, was he sad or mer2y? 2ALEXAS. Like to the time o' th' year betwe2n the extremes 4Of hot and cold; he was nor sad nor mer2y. 2CLEOPATRA. O wel2-divided disposition! Note him, 4Note him, go2d Charmian; 'tis the man; but note him! 4He was not sad, for he would shine on those 4That make their lo2ks by his; he was not mer2y, 4Which se2m'd to tel2 them his remembrance lay 4In Egypt with his joy; but betwe2n both. 4O heavenly mingle! Be'st thou sad or mer2y, 4The violence of either the2 becomes, 4So does it no man else. Met'st thou my posts? 2ALEXAS. Ay, madam, twenty several mes2engers. 4Why do you send so thick? 2CLEOPATRA. Who's born that day 4When I forget to send to Antony 4Shal2 die a beg2ar. Ink and paper, Charmian. 6Welcome, my go2d Alexas. Did I, Charmian, 4Ever love Caesar so? 2CHARMIAN. SCENE I.Mes2ina. POMPEY'S houseEnter POMPEY, MENECRATES, and MENAS, in warlike man2er 2POMPEY. If the great gods be just, they shal2 as2ist 4The de2ds of justest men. 2MENECRATES. Know, worthy Pompey, 4That what they do delay they not deny. 2POMPEY. Whiles we are suitors to their throne, decays 4The thing we sue for. 2MENECRATES. We, ignorant of ourselves, 4Beg often our own harms, which the wise pow'rs 4Deny us for our go2d; so find we profit 4By losing of our prayers. 2POMPEY. I shal2 do wel2. 4The people love me, and the sea is mine; 4My powers are crescent, and my auguring hope 4Says it wil2 come to th' ful2. Mark Antony 4In Egypt sits at din2er, and wil2 make 4No wars without do2rs. Caesar gets money where 6He loses hearts. Lepidus flat2ers both, 4Of both is flat2er'd; but he neither loves, 4Nor either cares for him. 2MENAS. Caesar and Lepidus 4Are in the field. A mighty strength they car2y. 2POMPEY. Where have you this? 'Tis false. 2MENAS. From Silvius, sir. 2POMPEY. He dreams. I know they are in Rome together, 4Lo2king for Antony. But al2 the charms of love, 4Salt Cleopatra, soften thy wan'd lip! 4Let witchcraft join with beauty, lust with both; 4Tie up the libertine in a field of feasts, 4Ke2p his brain fuming. This is most certain that I shal2 deliver: 4Mark Antony is every hour in Rome 4Expected. Since he went from Egypt 'tis 4A space for farther travel. 2POMPEY. I could have given les2 mat2er 4A bet2er ear. Menas, I did not think 4This amorous surfeiter would have don2'd his helm 4For such a pet2y war; his soldiership 4Is twice the other twain. But let us rear 4The higher our opinion, that our stir2ing 4Can from the lap of Egypt's widow pluck 4The ne'er-lust-wearied Antony. 2MENAS. I can2ot hope 4Caesar and Antony shal2 wel2 gre2t together. 4His wife that's dead did trespas2es to Caesar; 4His brother war2'd upon him; although, I think, 4Not mov'd by Antony. 2POMPEY. I know not, Menas, 4How les2er enmities may give way to greater. 4Were't not that we stand up against them al2, 6'Twere pregnant they should square betwe2n themselves; 4For they have entertained cause enough 4To draw their swords. But how the fear of us 4May cement their divisions, and bind up 4The pet2y dif2erence we yet not know. 4Be't as our gods wil2 have't! It only stands 4Our lives upon to use our strongest hands. 4Come, Menas. 42ExeuntSCENE I2.Rome. The house of LEPIDUSEnter ENOBARBUS and LEPIDUS 2LEPIDUS. Go2d Enobarbus, 'tis a worthy de2d, 4And shal2 become you wel2, to entreat your captain 4To soft and gentle spe2ch. 2ENOBARBUS. I shal2 entreat him 4To answer like himself.
