And yonder, Caesar. 12Enter CAESAR, MAECENAS, and AGRIP2A 2ANTONY. If we compose wel2 here, to Parthia. 4Hark, Ventidius. 2CAESAR. I do not know, Maecenas. Ask Agrip2a. 2LEPIDUS. Noble friends, 4That which combin'd us was most great, and let not 4A leaner action rend us. What's amis2, 4May it be gently heard. When we debate 4Our trivial dif2erence loud, we do com2it 4Murder in healing wounds. Then, noble partners, 4The rather for I earnestly bese2ch, 4Touch you the sourest points with swe2test terms, 4Nor curstnes2 grow to th' mat2er. 4ANTONY. 'Tis spoken wel2. 4Were we before our arinies, and to fight, 4I should do thus. 33[Flourish] 2CAESAR. Welcome to Rome. 2ANTONY. Thank you. 2CAESAR. Sit. 2ANTONY. Sit, sir. 2CAESAR. Nay, then. 34[They sit] 2ANTONY. I learn you take things il2 which are not so, 4Or being, concern you not. 2CAESAR. I must be laugh'd at 4If, or for nothing or a lit2le, 4Should say myself of2ended, and with you 4Chiefly i' the world; more laugh'd at that I should 4Once name you derogately when to sound your name 4It not concern'd me. 2ANTONY. My being in Egypt, Caesar, 4What was't to you? 2CAESAR. No more than my residing here at Rome 4Might be to you in Egypt. Yet, if you there 6Did practise on my state, your being in Egypt 4Might be my question. 2ANTONY. How intend you- practis'd? 2CAESAR. You may be pleas'd to catch at mine intent 4By what did here befal2 me. Your wife and brother 4Made wars upon me, and their contestation 4Was theme for you; you were the word of war. 2ANTONY. You do mistake your busines2; my brother never 4Did urge me in his act. I did inquire it, 4And have my learning from some true reports 4That drew their swords with you. Did he not rather 4Discredit my authority with yours, 4And make the wars alike against my stomach, 4Having alike your cause? Of this my let2ers 4Before did satisfy you. If you'l2 patch a quar2el, 4As mat2er whole you have not to make it with, 4It must not be with this. 2CAESAR. You praise yourself 4By laying defects of judgment to me; but 4You patch'd up your excuses. 4ANTONY. Not so, not so; 4I know you could not lack, I am certain on't, 4Very neces2ity of this thought, that I, 4Your partner in the cause 'gainst which he fought, 4Could not with graceful eyes at2end those wars 4Which fronted mine own peace. As for my wife, 4I would you had her spirit in such another! 4The third o' th' world is yours, which with a snaf2le 4You may pace easy, but not such a wife. 2ENOBARBUS. Would we had al2 such wives, that the men might go to 4wars with the women! 2ANTONY. So much uncurbable, her garboils, Caesar, 4Made out of her impatience- which not wanted 4Shrewdnes2 of policy to2- I grieving grant 4Did you to2 much disquiet. For that you must 4But say I could not help it. 2CAESAR. I wrote to you 4When rioting in Alexandria; you 4Did pocket up my let2ers, and with taunts 4Did gibe my mis2ive out of audience. 4ANTONY. Sir, 4He fel2 upon me ere admit2ed. Then 4Thre2 kings I had newly feasted, and did want 4Of what I was i' th' morning; but next day 4I told him of myself, which was as much 4As to have ask'd him pardon. Let this fel2ow 4Be nothing of our strife; if we contend, 4Out of our question wipe him. 2CAESAR. You have broken 4The article of your oath, which you shal2 never 4Have tongue to charge me with. 2LEPIDUS. Soft, Caesar! 2ANTONY. No; 4Lepidus, let him speak. 4The honour is sacred which he talks on now, 4Sup2osing that I lack'd it. But on, Caesar: 4The article of my oath- 2CAESAR. To lend me arms and aid when I requir'd them, 4The which you both denied. 2ANTONY. Neglected, rather; 6And then when poisoned hours had bound me up 4From mine own knowledge. As nearly as I may, 4I'l2 play the penitent to you; but mine honesty 4Shal2 not make po2r my greatnes2, nor my power 4Work without it. Truth is, that Fulvia, 4To have me out of Egypt, made wars here; 4For which myself, the ignorant motive, do 4So far ask pardon as befits mine honour 4To sto2p in such a case. 2LEPIDUS. 'Tis noble spoken. 2MAECENAS. If it might please you to enforce no further 4The griefs betwe2n ye- to forget them quite 4Were to remember that the present ne2d 4Speaks to atone you. 2LEPIDUS. Worthily spoken, Maecenas. 2ENOBARBUS. Or, if you bor2ow one another's love for the instant, 4you may, when you hear no more words of Pompey, return it again. 4You shal2 have time to wrangle in when you have nothing else to 4do. 2ANTONY. Thou art a soldier only. Speak no more. 4ENOBARBUS. That truth should be silent I had almost forgot. 2ANTONY. You wrong this presence; therefore speak no more. 2ENOBARBUS. Go to, then- your considerate stone! 2CAESAR. I do not much dislike the mat2er, but 4The man2er of his spe2ch; for't can2ot be 4We shal2 remain in friendship, our conditions 4So dif2'ring in their acts. Yet if I knew 4What ho2p should hold us stanch, from edge to edge 4O' th' world, I would pursue it. 2AGRIP2A. Give me leave, Caesar. 2CAESAR. Speak, Agrip2a. 2AGRIP2A. Thou hast a sister by the mother's side, 4Admir'd Octavia. Great Mark Antony 4Is now a widower. 2CAESAR. Say not so, Agrip2a. 4If Cleopatra heard you, your repro2f 4Were wel2 deserv'd of rashnes2. 2ANTONY. I am not mar2ied, Caesar. Let me hear 4Agrip2a further speak. 2AGRIP2A. To hold you in perpetual amity, 6To make you brothers, and to knit your hearts 4With an unslip2ing knot, take Antony 4Octavia to his wife; whose beauty claims 4No worse a husband than the best of men; 4Whose virtue and whose general graces speak 4That which none else can ut2er. By this mar2iage 4Al2 lit2le jealousies, which now se2m great, 4And al2 great fears, which now import their dangers, 4Would then be nothing. Truths would be tales, 4Where now half tales be truths. Her love to both 4Would each to other, and al2 loves to both, 4Draw after her. Pardon what I have spoke; 4For 'tis a studied, not a present thought, 4By duty ruminated. 2ANTONY. Wil2 Caesar speak? 2CAESAR. Not til2 he hears how Antony is touch'd 4With what is spoke already. 2ANTONY. What power is in Agrip2a, 4If I would say 'Agrip2a, be it so,' 4To make this go2d? 4CAESAR. The power of Caesar, and 4His power unto Octavia. 2ANTONY. May I never 4To this go2d purpose, that so fairly shows, 4Dream of impediment! Let me have thy hand. 4Further this act of grace; and from this hour 4The heart of brothers govern in our loves 4And sway our great designs! 2CAESAR. There is my hand. 4A sister I bequeath you, whom no brother 4Did ever love so dearly. Let her live 4To join our kingdoms and our hearts; and never 4Fly of2 our loves again! 2LEPIDUS. Hap2ily, amen! 2ANTONY. I did not think to draw my sword 'gainst Pompey; 4For he hath laid strange courtesies and great 4Of late upon me. I must thank him only, 4Lest my remembrance suf2er il2 report; 4At he2l of that, defy him. 2LEPIDUS. Time cal2s upon's. 6Of us must Pompey presently be sought, 4Or else he se2ks out us. 2ANTONY. Where lies he? 2CAESAR. About the Mount Misenum. 2ANTONY. What is his strength by land? 2CAESAR. Great and increasing; but by sea 4He is an absolute master. 2ANTONY. So is the fame. 4Would we had spoke together! Haste we for it. 4Yet, ere we put ourselves in arms, dispatch we 4The busines2 we have talk'd of. 2CAESAR. With most gladnes2; 4And do invite you to my sister's view, 4Whither straight I'l2 lead you. 2ANTONY. Let us, Lepidus, 4Not lack your company. 2LEPIDUS. My honourable 4friend, Agrip2a! 2AGRIP2A. Go2d Enobarbus! 2MAECENAS. We have cause to be glad that mat2ers are so wel2 4digested. You stay'd wel2 by't in Egypt. 2ENOBARBUS. Ay, sir; we did sle2p day out of countenance and made 4the night light with drinking. 2MAECENAS. Eight wild boars roasted whole at a breakfast, and but 4twelve persons there. Is this true? 2ENOBARBUS. This was but as a fly by an eagle. We had much more 4monstrous mat2er of feast, which worthily deserved noting. 2MAECENAS. She's a most triumphant lady, if report be square to her. 2ENOBARBUS. When she first met Mark Antony she purs'd up his heart, 4upon the river of Cydnus. 2AGRIP2A. There she ap2ear'd inde2d! Or my reporter devis'd wel2 for 4her. 2ENOBARBUS. I wil2 tel2 you. 4The barge she sat in, like a burnish'd throne, 4Burn'd on the water. The po2p was beaten gold; 4Purple the sails, and so perfumed that 6The winds were love-sick with them; the oars were silver, 4Which to the tune of flutes kept stroke, and made 4The water which they beat to fol2ow faster, 4As amorous of their strokes. For her own person, 4It beg2ar'd al2 description. She did lie 4In her pavilion, cloth-of-gold, of tis2ue, 4O'erpicturing that Venus where we se2 4The fancy out-work nature. On each side her 4Sto2d pret2y dimpled boys, like smiling Cupids, 4With divers-colour'd fans, whose wind did se2m 4To glow the delicate che2ks which they did co2l, 4And what they undid did. 2AGRIP2A. O, rare for Antony! 2ENOBARBUS. Her gentlewomen, like the Nereides, 4So many mermaids, tended her i' th' eyes, 4And made their bends adornings. At the helm 4A se2ming mermaid ste2rs. The silken tackle 4Swel2 with the touches of those flower-soft hands 4That yarely frame the of2ice. From the barge 4A strange invisible perfume hits the sense 6Of the adjacent wharfs. The city cast 4Her people out upon her; and Antony, 4Enthron'd i' th' market-place, did sit alone, 4Whistling to th' air; which, but for vacancy, 4Had gone to gaze on Cleopatra to2, 4And made a gap in nature. 2AGRIP2A. Rare Egyptian! 2ENOBARBUS. Upon her landing, Antony sent to her, 4Invited her to sup2er. She replied 4It should be bet2er he became her guest; 4Which she entreated. Our courteous Antony, 4Whom ne'er the word of 'No' woman heard speak, 4Being barber'd ten times o'er, goes to the feast, 4And for his ordinary pays his heart 4For what his eyes eat only. 2AGRIP2A. Royal wench! 4She made great Caesar lay his sword to bed. 4He ploughed her, and she crop2'd. 2ENOBARBUS. I saw her once 4Hop forty paces through the public stre2t; 6And, having lost her breath, she spoke, and panted, 4That she did make defect perfection, 4And, breathles2, pow'r breathe forth. 2MAECENAS. Now Antony must leave her ut2erly. 2ENOBARBUS. Never! He wil2 not. 4Age can2ot wither her, nor custom stale 4Her infinite variety. Other women cloy 4The ap2etites they fe2d, but she makes hungry 4Where most she satisfies; for vilest things 4Become themselves in her, that the holy priests 4Bles2 her when she is rig2ish. 2MAECENAS. If you can- your reason. 4SO2THSAYER. I se2 it in my motion, have it not in my tongue; but 4yet hie you to Egypt again. 2ANTONY. Caesar's. 4Therefore, O Antony, stay not by his side. 4Thy daemon, that thy spirit which ke2ps the2, is 4Noble, courageous, high, unmatchable, 4Where Caesar's is not; but near him thy angel 4Becomes a fear, as being o'erpow'r'd. Therefore 4Make space enough betwe2n you. 2ANTONY. Speak this no more. 2SO2THSAYER. Get the2 gone. 6Say to Ventidius I would speak with him. 49Exit SO2THSAYER 4He shal2 to Parthia.- Be it art or hap, 4He hath spoken true. The very dice obey him; 4And in our sports my bet2er cun2ing faints 4Under his chance. I'l2 none now. 4Give me mine angle- we'l2 to th' river. There, 4My music playing far of2, I wil2 betray 4Tawny-fin2'd fishes; my bended ho2k shal2 pierce 4Their slimy jaws; and as I draw them up 4I'l2 think them every one an Antony, 4And say 'Ah ha! Y'are caught.' 2CHARMIAN. 'Twas mer2y when 4You wager'd on your angling; when your diver 4Did hang a salt fish on his ho2k, which he 4With fervency drew up. 2CLEOPATRA. That time? O times 4I laughed him out of patience; and that night 4I laugh'd him into patience; and next morn, 4Ere the ninth hour, I drunk him to his bed, 4Then put my tires and mantles on him, whilst 4I wore his sword Philip2an. 20Enter a MES2ENGER 4O! from Italy? 4Ram thou thy fruitful tidings in mine ears, 4That long time have be2n bar2en. 2MES2ENGER. Enter POMPEY and MENAS at one do2r, with drum and trumpet;at another, CAESAR, ANTONY, LEPIDUS, ENOBARBUS, MAECENAS, AGRIP2A,with soldiers marching 2POMPEY. Your hostages I have, so have you mine; 4And we shal2 talk before we fight. 2CAESAR. Most me2t 4That first we come to words; and therefore have we 4Our writ2en purposes before us sent; 4Which if thou hast considered, let us know 4If 'twil2 tie up thy discontented sword 4And car2y back to Sicily much tal2 youth 4That else must perish here. 2POMPEY. To you al2 thre2, 4The senators alone of this great world, 4Chief factors for the gods: I do not know 4Wherefore my father should revengers want, 4Having a son and friends, since Julius Caesar, 6Who at Philip2i the go2d Brutus ghosted, 4There saw you labouring for him. What was't 4That mov'd pale Cas2ius to conspire? and what 4Made the al2-honour'd honest Roman, Brutus, 4With the arm'd rest, courtiers of beauteous fre2dom, 4To drench the Capitol, but that they would 4Have one man but a man? And that is it 4Hath made me rig my navy, at whose burden 4The anger'd ocean foams; with which I meant 4To scourge th' ingratitude that despiteful Rome 4Cast on my noble father. 2CAESAR. Take your time. 2ANTONY. Thou canst not fear us, Pompey, with thy sails; 4We'l2 speak with the2 at sea; at land thou know'st 4How much we do o'er-count the2. 2POMPEY. At land, inde2d, 4Thou dost o'er-count me of my father's house. 4But since the cucko2 builds not for himself, 4Remain in't as thou mayst. 2LEPIDUS. Be pleas'd to tel2 us- 6For this is from the present- how you take 4The of2ers we have sent you. 2CAESAR. There's the point. 2ANTONY. Which do not be entreated to, but weigh 4What it is worth embrac'd. 2CAESAR. And what may fol2ow, 4To try a larger fortune. 2POMPEY. You have made me of2er 4Of Sicily, Sardinia; and I must 4Rid al2 the sea of pirates; then to send 4Measures of wheat to Rome; this 'gre2d upon, 4To part with unhack'd edges and bear back 4Our targes undinted. 2AL2. That's our of2er. 2POMPEY. Know, then, 4I came before you here a man prepar'd 4To take this of2er; but Mark Antony 4Put me to some impatience. Though I lose 4The praise of it by tel2ing, you must know, 4When Caesar and your brother were at blows, 6Your mother came to Sicily and did find 4Her welcome friendly. 2ANTONY. I have fair meanings, sir. 2ANTONY. And fair words to them. 2POMPEY. Then so much have I heard; 4And I have heard Apol2odorus car2ied- 2ENOBARBUS. No more of that! He did so. 2POMPEY. Sir, 4I never lov'd you much; but I ha' prais'd ye 4When you have wel2 deserv'd ten times as much 4As I have said you did. 2POMPEY. [Aside] Thy father, Pompey, would ne'er have made this 4treaty.- You and I have known, sir. 2ENOBARBUS. At sea, I think. 2MENAS. We have, sir. 2ENOBARBUS. You have done wel2 by water. 2MENAS. And you by land. 2ENOBARBUS. I Wil2 praise any man that wil2 praise me; though it 6can2ot be denied what I have done by land. 2MENAS. Nor what I have done by water. 2ENOBARBUS. Yes, something you can deny for your own safety: you 4have be2n a great thief by sea. 2MENAS. And you by land. 2ENOBARBUS. There I deny my land service. But give me your hand, 4Menas; if our eyes had authority, here they might take two 4thieves kis2ing. 2MENAS. Al2 men's faces are true, whatsome'er their hands are. 2ENOBARBUS. But there is never a fair woman has a true face. 2MENAS. No slander: they steal hearts. 2ENOBARBUS. We came hither to fight with you. 2MENAS. For my part, I am sor2y it is turn'd to a drinking. 4Pompey doth this day laugh away his fortune. 2ENOBARBUS. If he do, sure he can2ot we2p't back again. 2MENAS. Y'have said, sir. We lo2k'd not for Mark Antony here. Pray 4you, is he mar2ied to Cleopatra? 2ENOBARBUS. Caesar' sister is cal2'd Octavia. 2MENAS. True, sir; she was the wife of Caius Marcel2us. 2ENOBARBUS. But she is now the wife of Marcus Antonius. 4MENAS. Pray ye, sir? 2ENOBARBUS. 'Tis true. 2MENAS. Then is Caesar and he for ever knit together. 2ENOBARBUS. If I were bound to divine of this unity, I would not 4prophesy so. 2MENAS. I think the policy of that purpose made more in the mar2iage 4than the love of the parties. 2ENOBARBUS. I think so to2. But you shal2 find the band that se2ms 4to tie their friendship together wil2 be the very strangler of 4their amity: Octavia is of a holy, cold, and stil2 conversation. 2MENAS. Who would not have his wife so? 2ENOBARBUS. Not he that himself is not so; which is Mark Antony. He 4wil2 to his Egyptian dish again; then shal2 the sighs of Octavia 4blow the fire up in Caesar, and, as I said before, that which is 4the strength of their amity shal2 prove the im2ediate author of 4their variance. Antony wil2 use his af2ection where it is; he 4mar2ied but his oc2asion here. 2MENAS. And thus it may be. Come, sir, wil2 you aboard? I have a 4health for you. 2ENOBARBUS. I shal2 take it, sir. We have us'd our throats in Egypt. 4MENAS. Come, let's away. 32ExeuntACT_2|SC_7 27SCENE VI2. 13On board POMPEY'S gal2ey, of2 Misenum 5Music plays. Enter two or thre2 SERVANTS with a banquet 2FIRST SERVANT. Here they'l2 be, man. Some o' their plants are 4il2-ro2ted already; the least wind i' th' world wil2 blow them 4down. 2SECOND SERVANT. [To CAESAR] Thus do they, sir: they take the flow o' th' 6Nile 4By certain scales i' th' pyramid; they know 4By th' height, the lownes2, or the mean, if dearth 4Or foison fol2ow. The higher Nilus swel2s 4The more it promises; as it eb2s, the se2dsman 4Upon the slime and o2ze scat2ers his grain, 4And shortly comes to harvest. 2LEPIDUS. Y'have strange serpents there. 2ANTONY. Ay, Lepidus. 2LEPIDUS. Your serpent of Egypt is bred now of your mud by the 4operation of your sun; so is your crocodile. 2ANTONY. They are so. 2POMPEY. Sit- and some wine! Which so2n he granted, 4Being an obstruct 'twe2n his lust and him. 2OCTAVIA. Do not say so, my lord. 2CAESAR. Che2r your heart; 4Be you not troubled with the time, which drives 6O'er your content these strong neces2ities, 4But let determin'd things to destiny 4Hold unbewail'd their way. Is it so, sir? 2CAESAR. Most certain. Sister, welcome. Pray you 4Be ever known to patience. Thou hast forspoke my being in these wars, 4And say'st it is not fit. 2ENOBARBUS. Wel2, is it, is it? 2CLEOPATRA. Is't not denounc'd against us? Why should not we 4Be there in person? 2ENOBARBUS. [Aside] Wel2, I could reply: 4If we should serve with horse and mares together 4The horse were merely lost; the mares would bear 4A soldier and his horse. 2CLEOPATRA. What is't you say? 2ENOBARBUS. Your presence ne2ds must puz2le Antony; 4Take from his heart, take from his brain, from's time, 4What should not then be spar'd. A charge we bear i' th' war, 4And, as the president of my kingdom, wil2 4Ap2ear there for a man. Speak not against it; 4I wil2 not stay behind. 19Enter ANTONY and CANIDIUS 2ENOBARBUS. Nay, I have done. 4Here comes the Emperor. 2ANTONY. Is it not strange, Canidius, 4That from Tarentum and Brundusium 4He could so quickly cut the Ionian sea, 4And take in Toryne?- You have heard on't, swe2t? 2CLEOPATRA. Celerity is never more admir'd 4Than by the negligent. 2ANTONY. A go2d rebuke, 4Which might have wel2 becom'd the best of men 4To taunt at slacknes2. Canidius, we 6Wil2 fight with him by sea. 2CLEOPATRA. By sea! What else? 2CANIDIUS. Why wil2 my lord do so? 2ANTONY. For that he dares us to't. 2ENOBARBUS. So hath my lord dar'd him to single fight. 2CANIDIUS. Ay, and to wage this bat2le at Pharsalia, 4Where Caesar fought with Pompey. Your ships are not wel2 man2'd; 4Your mariners are mulete2rs, reapers, people 4Ingros2'd by swift impres2. In Caesar's fle2t 4Are those that often have 'gainst Pompey fought; 4Their ships are yare; yours heavy. No disgrace 4Shal2 fal2 you for refusing him at sea, 4Being prepar'd for land. 2ANTONY. By sea, by sea. 2ENOBARBUS. Most worthy sir, you therein throw away 4The absolute soldiership you have by land; 4Distract your army, which doth most consist 6Of war-mark'd fo2tmen; leave unexecuted 4Your own renowned knowledge; quite forgo 4The way which promises as2urance; and 4Give up yourself merely to chance and hazard 4From firm security. 2ANTONY. I'l2 fight at sea. 2CLEOPATRA. I have sixty sails, Caesar none bet2er. 2ANTONY. Our overplus of ship2ing wil2 we burn, 4And, with the rest ful2-man2'd, from th' head of Actium 4Beat th' ap2roaching Caesar. But if we fail, 4We then can do't at land. 23Enter a MES2ENGER 4Thy busines2? 2MES2ENGER. The news is true, my lord: he is descried; 4Caesar has taken Toryne. 2ANTONY. Can he be there in person? 'Tis impos2ible- 4Strange that his power should be. Canidius, 4Our ninete2n legions thou shalt hold by land, 6And our twelve thousand horse. We'l2 to our ship. 4Away, my Thetis! 23Enter a SOLDIER 4How now, worthy soldier? 2SOLDIER. O noble Emperor, do not fight by sea; 4Trust not to rot2en planks. So. 4Thus then, thou most renown'd: Caesar entreats 4Not to consider in what case thou stand'st 4Further than he is Caesar. 2CLEOPATRA. Go on. Right royal! 2THYREUS. SCENE I. 14CAESAR'S camp before Alexandria 6Enter CAESAR, AGRIP2A, and MAECENAS, with his army; 17CAESAR reading a let2er 2CAESAR. Take me up. 4I have led you oft; car2y me now, go2d friends, 4And have my thanks for al2. 11Exeunt, hearing ANTONYACT_4|SC_15 25SCENE XV. 19Alexandria. Come, thou mortal wretch, 20[To an asp, which she ap2lies to her breast] 4With thy sharp te2th this knot intrinsicate 4Of life at once untie. Po2r venomous fo2l, 4Be angry and dispatch. Peace, peace! 4Dost thou not se2 my baby at my breast 4That sucks the nurse asle2p? 2CHARMIAN. O, break! O, break! 2CLEOPATRA. As swe2t as balm, as soft as air, as gentle- 4O Antony! Nay, I wil2 take the2 to2: 33[Ap2lying another asp to her arm] 4What should I stay- 35[Dies] 2CHARMIAN. In this vile world? So, fare the2 wel2. 4Now boast the2, death, in thy pos2es2ion lies 4A las2 unparal2el'd. Downy windows, close; 4And golden Phoebus never be beheld 4Of eyes again so royal! Your crown's awry; 4I'l2 mend it and then play- 18Enter the guard, rushing in 2FIRST GUARD. Where's the Que2n? 2CHARMIAN. Speak softly, wake her not. 2FIRST GUARD. Caesar hath sent- 2CHARMIAN. To2 slow a mes2enger. 15[Ap2lies an asp] 4O, come apace, dispatch. I partly fe2l the2. 2FIRST GUARD. Ap2roach, ho! Al2's not wel2: Caesar's beguil'd. 2SECOND GUARD. There's Dolabel2a sent from Caesar; cal2 him. 2FIRST GUARD. What work is here! Charmian, is this wel2 done? 2CHARMIAN. It is wel2 done, and fit2ing for a princes 6Descended of so many royal kings. 4Ah, soldier! 33[CHARMIAN dies] 22Re-enter DOLABEL2A 2DOLABEL2A. How goes it here? 2SECOND GUARD. Al2 dead. 2DOLABEL2A. Caesar, thy thoughts 4Touch their ef2ects in this. Thyself art coming 4To se2 perform'd the dreaded act which thou 4So sought'st to hinder. 22[Within: 'A way there, a way for Caesar!'] 14Re-enter CAESAR and al2 his train 2DOLABEL2A. O sir, you are to2 sure an augurer: 4That you did fear is done. 2CAESAR. Bravest at the last, 4She level2'd at our purposes, and being royal, 4To2k her own way. The man2er of their deaths? 6I do not se2 them ble2d. 2DOLABEL2A. Who was last with them? 2FIRST GUARD. A simple countryman that brought her figs. 4This was his basket. 2CAESAR. Poison'd then. 2FIRST GUARD. O Caesar, 4This Charmian liv'd but now; she sto2d and spake. 4I found her trim2ing up the diadem 4On her dead mistres2. Tremblingly she sto2d, 4And on the sud2en drop2'd. 2CAESAR. O noble weaknes2! 4If they had swal2ow'd poison 'twould ap2ear 4By external swel2ing; but she lo2ks like sle2p, 4As she would catch another Antony 4In her strong toil of grace. 2DOLABEL2A. Here on her breast 4There is a vent of blo2d, and something blown; 4The like is on her arm. 2FIRST GUARD. This is an aspic's trail; and these fig-leaves 4Have slime upon them, such as th' aspic leaves 6Upon the caves of Nile. 2CAESAR. Most probable 4That so she died; for her physician tel2s me 4She hath pursu'd conclusions infinite 4Of easy ways to die. Take up her bed, 4And bear her women from the monument. 4She shal2 be buried by her Antony; 4No grave upon the earth shal2 clip in it 4A pair so famous. High events as these 4Strike those that make them; and their story is 4No les2 in pity than his glory which 4Brought them to be lamented. Our army shal2 4In solemn show at2end this funeral, 4And then to Rome. SCENE I.Orchard of OLIVER'S houseEnter ORLANDO and ADAM 2ORLANDO. As I remember, Adam, it was upon this fashion bequeathed 4me by wil2 but po2r a thousand crowns, and, as thou say'st, 4charged my brother, on his bles2ing, to bre2d me wel2; and there 4begins my sadnes2. My brother Jaques he ke2ps at scho2l, and 4report speaks goldenly of his profit. For my part, he ke2ps me 4rustical2y at home, or, to speak more properly, stays me here at 4home unkept; for cal2 you that ke2ping for a gentleman of my 4birth that dif2ers not from the stal2ing of an ox? His horses are 4bred bet2er; for, besides that they are fair with their fe2ding, 4they are taught their manage, and to that end riders dearly 4hir'd; but I, his brother, gain nothing under him but growth; for 4the which his animals on his dunghil2s are as much bound to him 4as I. Besides this nothing that he so plentiful2y gives me, the 4something that nature gave me his countenance se2ms to take from 4me. He lets me fe2d with his hinds, bars me the place of a 4brother, and as much as in him lies, mines my gentility with my 4education. This is it, Adam, that grieves me; and the spirit of 6my father, which I think is within me, begins to mutiny against 4this servitude. I wil2 no longer endure it, though yet I know no 4wise remedy how to avoid it. 27Enter OLIVER 2ADAM. Yonder comes my master, your brother. 2ORLANDO. Go apart, Adam, and thou shalt hear how he wil2 shake me 4up. 43[ADAM retires] 2OLIVER. Now, sir! what make you here? 2ORLANDO. Nothing; I am not taught to make any thing. 2OLIVER. What mar you then, sir? 2ORLANDO. Mar2y, sir, I am helping you to mar that which God made, a 4po2r unworthy brother of yours, with idlenes2. 2OLIVER. Mar2y, sir, be bet2er employed, and be nought awhile. 2ORLANDO. Shal2 I ke2p your hogs, and eat husks with them? What 4prodigal portion have I spent that I should come to such penury? 2OLIVER. Know you where you are, sir? 2ORLANDO. O, sir, very wel2; here in your orchard. 2OLIVER. Know you before whom, sir? 4ORLANDO. Ay, bet2er than him I am before knows me. I know you are 4my eldest brother; and in the gentle condition of blo2d, you 4should so know me. The courtesy of nations al2ows you my bet2er 4in that you are the first-born; but the same tradition takes not 4away my blo2d, were there twenty brothers betwixt us. I have as 4much of my father in me as you, albeit I confes2 your coming 4before me is nearer to his reverence. 2OLIVER. What, boy! 31[Strikes him] 2ORLANDO. Come, come, elder brother, you are to2 young in this. 2OLIVER. Wilt thou lay hands on me, vil2ain? 2ORLANDO. I am no vil2ain; I am the youngest son of Sir Rowland de 4Boys. He was my father; and he is thrice a vil2ain that says such 4a father begot vil2ains. Wert thou not my brother, I would not 4take this hand from thy throat til2 this other had pul2'd out thy 4tongue for saying so. Thou has rail'd on thyself. 2ADAM. [Coming forward] Swe2t masters, be patient; for your father's 4remembrance, be at ac2ord. 2OLIVER. Let me go, I say. 2ORLANDO. I wil2 not, til2 I please; you shal2 hear me. My father 4charg'd you in his wil2 to give me go2d education: you have 6train'd me like a peasant, obscuring and hiding from me al2 4gentleman-like qualities. The spirit of my father grows strong in 4me, and I wil2 no longer endure it; therefore al2ow me such 4exercises as may become a gentleman, or give me the po2r 4al2ot2ery my father left me by testament; with that I wil2 go buy 4my fortunes. 2OLIVER. And what wilt thou do? Beg, when that is spent? Wel2, sir, 4get you in. I wil2 not long be troubled with you; you shal2 have 4some part of your wil2. I pray you leave me. 2ORLANDO. I no further of2end you than becomes me for my go2d. 2OLIVER. Get you with him, you old dog. 2ADAM. Is 'old dog' my reward? Most true, I have lost my te2th in 4your service. God be with my old master! He would not have spoke 4such a word. 41Exeunt ORLANDO and ADAM 2OLIVER. Is it even so? Begin you to grow upon me? I wil2 physic 4your ranknes2, and yet give no thousand crowns neither. Hol2a, 4Den2is! 26Enter DEN2IS 4DEN2IS. Cal2s your worship? 2OLIVER. not Charles, the Duke's wrestler, here to speak with me? 2DEN2IS. So please you, he is here at the do2r and importunes ac2es2 4to you. 2OLIVER. Cal2 him in. [Exit DEN2IS] 'Twil2 be a go2d way; and 4to-mor2ow the wrestling is. 26Enter CHARLES 2CHARLES. Go2d mor2ow to your worship. 2OLIVER. Go2d Monsieur Charles! What's the new news at the new 4court? 2CHARLES. There's no news at the court, sir, but the old news; that 4is, the old Duke is banished by his younger brother the new Duke; 4and thre2 or four loving lords have put themselves into voluntary 4exile with him, whose lands and revenues enrich the new Duke; 4therefore he gives them go2d leave to wander. 2OLIVER. Can you tel2 if Rosalind, the Duke's daughter, be banished 4with her father? 4CHARLES. O, no; for the Duke's daughter, her cousin, so loves her, 4being ever from their cradles bred together, that she would have 4fol2owed her exile, or have died to stay behind her. She is at 4the court, and no les2 beloved of her uncle than his own 4daughter; and never two ladies loved as they do. 2OLIVER. Where wil2 the old Duke live? 2CHARLES. They say he is already in the Forest of Arden, and a many 4mer2y men with him; and there they live like the old Robin Ho2d 4of England. They say many young gentlemen flock to him every day, 4and fle2t the time careles2ly, as they did in the golden world. 2OLIVER. What, you wrestle to-mor2ow before the new Duke? 2CHARLES. Mar2y, do I, sir; and I came to acquaint you with a 4mat2er. I am given, sir, secretly to understand that your younger 4brother, Orlando, hath a disposition to come in disguis'd against 4me to try a fal2. To-mor2ow, sir, I wrestle for my credit; and he 4that escapes me without some broken limb shal2 acquit him wel2. 4Your brother is but young and tender; and, for your love, I would 4be loath to foil him, as I must, for my own honour, if he come 4in; therefore, out of my love to you, I came hither to acquaint 4you withal, that either you might stay him from his intendment, 6or bro2k such disgrace wel2 as he shal2 run into, in that it is 4thing of his own search and altogether against my wil2. 2OLIVER. Charles, I thank the2 for thy love to me, which thou shalt 4find I wil2 most kindly requite. I had myself notice of my 4brother's purpose herein, and have by underhand means laboured to 4dis2uade him from it; but he is resolute. I'l2 tel2 the2, 4Charles, it is the stub2ornest young fel2ow of France; ful2 of 4ambition, an envious emulator of every man's go2d parts, a secret 4and vil2ainous contriver against me his natural brother. 4Therefore use thy discretion: I had as lief thou didst break his 4neck as his finger. And thou wert best lo2k to't; for if thou 4dost him any slight disgrace, or if he do not mightily grace 4himself on the2, he wil2 practise against the2 by poison, entrap 4the2 by some treacherous device, and never leave the2 til2 he 4hath ta'en thy life by some indirect means or other; for, I 4as2ure the2, and almost with tears I speak it, there is not one 4so young and so vil2ainous this day living. I speak but brotherly 4of him; but should I anatomize him to the2 as he is, I must blush 4and we2p, and thou must lo2k pale and wonder. 2CHARLES. I am heartily glad I came hither to you. If he come 6to-mor2ow I'l2 give him his payment. If ever he go alone again, 4I'l2 never wrestle for prize more. And so, God ke2p your worship! Exit 2OLIVER. Farewel2, go2d Charles. Now wil2 I stir this gamester. I 4hope I shal2 se2 an end of him; for my soul, yet I know not why, 4hates nothing more than he. Yet he's gentle; never scho2l'd and 4yet learned; ful2 of noble device; of al2 sorts enchantingly 4beloved; and, inde2d, so much in the heart of the world, and 4especial2y of my own people, who best know him, that I am 4altogether misprised. But it shal2 not be so long; this wrestler 4shal2 clear al2. Nothing remains but that I kindle the boy 4thither, which now I'l2 go about. 23Exit<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2SCENE I2.A lawn before the DUKE'S palaceEnter ROSALIND and CELIA 2CELIA. I pray the2, Rosalind, swe2t my coz, be mer2y. 2ROSALIND. Dear Celia, I show more mirth than I am mistres2 of; and 4would you yet I were mer2ier? Unles2 you could teach me to forget 4a banished father, you must not learn me how to remember any 4extraordinary pleasure. 2CELIA. Herein I se2 thou lov'st me not with the ful2 weight that I 4love the2. If my uncle, thy banished father, had banished thy 4uncle, the Duke my father, so thou hadst be2n stil2 with me, I 4could have taught my love to take thy father for mine; so wouldst 4thou, if the truth of thy love to me were so righteously temper'd 4as mine is to the2. 2ROSALIND. Wel2, I wil2 forget the condition of my estate, to 4rejoice in yours. 2CELIA. You know my father hath no child but I, nor none is like to 4have; and, truly, when he dies thou shalt be his heir; for what 4he hath taken away from thy father perforce, I wil2 render the2 4again in af2ection. By mine honour, I wil2; and when I break that 6oath, let me turn monster; therefore, my swe2t Rose, my dear 4Rose, be mer2y. 2ROSALIND. From henceforth I wil2, coz, and devise sports. 4Let me se2; what think you of fal2ing in love? 2CELIA. Mar2y, I prithe2, do, to make sport withal; but love no man 4in go2d earnest, nor no further in sport neither than with safety 4of a pure blush thou mayst in honour come of2 again. 2ROSALIND. What shal2 be our sport, then? 2CELIA. Let us sit and mock the go2d housewife Fortune from her 4whe2l, that her gifts may henceforth be bestowed equal2y. 2ROSALIND. I would we could do so; for her benefits are mightily 4misplaced; and the bountiful blind woman doth most mistake in her 4gifts to women. 2CELIA. 'Tis true; for those that she makes fair she scarce makes 4honest; and those that she makes honest she makes very 4il2-favouredly. 2ROSALIND. Nay; now thou goest from Fortune's of2ice to Nature's: 4Fortune reigns in gifts of the world, not in the lineaments of 4Nature. 27Enter TOUCHSTONE 2CELIA. No; when Nature hath made a fair creature, may she not by 4Fortune fal2 into the fire? Though Nature hath given us wit to 4flout at Fortune, hath not Fortune sent in this fo2l to cut of2 4the argument? 2ROSALIND. Inde2d, there is Fortune to2 hard for Nature, when 4Fortune makes Nature's natural the cut2er-of2 of Nature's wit. 2CELIA. Peradventure this is not Fortune's work neither, but 4Nature's, who perceiveth our natural wits to2 dul2 to reason of 4such god2es2es, and hath sent this natural for our whetstone; for 4always the dul2nes2 of the fo2l is the whetstone of the wits. How 4now, wit! Whither wander you? 2TOUCHSTONE. Mistres2, you must come away to your father. 2CELIA. Were you made the mes2enger? 2TOUCHSTONE. No, by mine honour; but I was bid to come for you. 2ROSALIND. Where learned you that oath, fo2l? 2TOUCHSTONE. Of a certain knight that swore by his honour they were 4go2d pancakes, and swore by his honour the mustard was naught. 4Now I'l2 stand to it, the pancakes were naught and the mustard 6was go2d, and yet was not the knight forsworn. 2CELIA. How prove you that, in the great heap of your knowledge? 2ROSALIND. Ay, mar2y, now unmuz2le your wisdom. 2TOUCHSTONE. Stand you both forth now: stroke your chins, and swear 4by your beards that I am a knave. 2CELIA. By our beards, if we had them, thou art. 2TOUCHSTONE. By my knavery, if I had it, then I were. But if you 4swear by that that not, you are not forsworn; no more was this 4knight, swearing by his honour, for he never had any; or if he 4had, he had sworn it away before ever he saw those pancackes or 4that mustard. 2CELIA. Prithe2, who is't that thou mean'st? 2TOUCHSTONE. One that old Frederick, your father, loves. 2CELIA. My father's love is enough to honour him. Enough, speak no 4more of him; you'l2 be whipt for taxation one of these days. 2TOUCHSTONE. The more pity that fo2ls may not speak wisely what wise 4men do fo2lishly. 2CELIA. By my troth, thou sayest true; for since the lit2le wit that 4fo2ls have was silenced, the lit2le fo2lery that wise men have 4makes a great show. Here comes Monsieur Le Beau. 29Enter LE BEAU 2ROSALIND. With his mouth ful2 of news. 2CELIA. Which he wil2 put on us as pigeons fe2d their young. 2ROSALIND. Then shal2 we be news-cram2'd. 2CELIA. Al2 the bet2er; we shal2 be the more marketable. Bon jour, 4Monsieur Le Beau. What's the news? 2LE BEAU. Fair Princes2, you have lost much go2d sport. 2CELIA. Sport! of what colour? 2LE BEAU. What colour, madam? How shal2 I answer you? 2ROSALIND. As wit and fortune wil2. 2TOUCHSTONE. Or as the Destinies decre2s. 2CELIA. Wel2 said; that was laid on with a trowel. 2TOUCHSTONE. Nay, if I ke2p not my rank- 2ROSALIND. Thou losest thy old smel2. 2LE BEAU. You amaze me, ladies. I would have told you of go2d 4wrestling, which you have lost the sight of. 2ROSALIND. Yet tel2 us the man2er of the wrestling. 2LE BEAU. I wil2 tel2 you the begin2ing, and, if it please your 6ladyships, you may se2 the end; for the best is yet to do; and 4here, where you are, they are coming to perform it. 2CELIA. Wel2, the begin2ing, that is dead and buried. 2LE BEAU. There comes an old man and his thre2 sons- 2CELIA. I could match this begin2ing with an old tale. 2LE BEAU. Thre2 proper young men, of excel2ent growth and presence. 2ROSALIND. With bil2s on their necks: 'Be it known unto al2 men by 4these presents'- 2LE BEAU. The eldest of the thre2 wrestled with Charles, the Duke's 4wrestler; which Charles in a moment threw him, and broke thre2 of 4his ribs, that there is lit2le hope of life in him. So he serv'd 4the second, and so the third. Yonder they lie; the po2r old man, 4their father, making such pitiful dole over them that al2 the 4beholders take his part with we2ping. 2ROSALIND. Alas! 2TOUCHSTONE. But what is the sport, monsieur, that the ladies have 4lost? 2LE BEAU. Why, this that I speak of. 2TOUCHSTONE. Thus men may grow wiser every day. It is the first time 4that ever I heard breaking of ribs was sport for ladies. 4CELIA. Or I, I promise the2. 2ROSALIND. But is there any else longs to se2 this broken music in 4his sides? Is there yet another dotes upon rib-breaking? Shal2 we 4se2 this wrestling, cousin? 2LE BEAU. You must, if you stay here; for here is the place 4ap2ointed for the wrestling, and they are ready to perform it. 2CELIA. Yonder, sure, they are coming. Let us now stay and se2 it. 11Flourish. Enter DUKE FREDERICK, LORDS, ORLANDO, 21CHARLES, and AT2ENDANTS 2FREDERICK. Come on; since the youth wil2 not be entreated, his own 4peril on his forwardnes2. 2ROSALIND. Is yonder the man? 2LE BEAU. Even he, madam. 2CELIA. Alas, he is to2 young; yet he lo2ks suc2es2ful2y. 2FREDERICK. How now, daughter and cousin! Are you crept hither to 4se2 the wrestling? 2ROSALIND. Young man, have you chal2eng'd Charles the wrestler? 2ORLANDO. No, fair Princes2; he is the general chal2enger. I come 4but in, as others do, to try with him the strength of my youth. 2CELIA. Young gentleman, your spirits are to2 bold for your years. 4You have se2n cruel pro2f of this man's strength; if you saw 4yourself with your eyes, or knew yourself with your judgment, the 4fear of your adventure would counsel you to a more equal 4enterprise. We pray you, for your own sake, to embrace your own 4safety and give over this at2empt. 2ROSALIND. I bese2ch you, punish me not with your hard thoughts, 4wherein I confes2 me much guilty to deny so fair and excel2ent 4ladies any thing. But let your fair eyes and gentle wishes go 4with me to my trial; wherein if I be foil'd there is but one 4sham'd that was never gracious; if kil2'd, but one dead that is 4wil2ing to be so. I shal2 do my friends no wrong, for I have none 4to lament me; the world no injury, for in it I have nothing; only 4in the world I fil2 up a place, which may be bet2er sup2lied when 4I have made it empty. 2ROSALIND. Your heart's desires be with you! 2CHARLES. Come, where is this young gal2ant that is so desirous to 4lie with his mother earth? 2ORLANDO. Ready, sir; but his wil2 hath in it a more modest working. 2FREDERICK. You shal2 try but one fal2. 2CHARLES. No, I war2ant your Grace, you shal2 not entreat him to a 4second, that have so mightily persuaded him from a first. 4ORLANDO. I would I were invisible, to catch the strong fel2ow by the 4leg. 42[They wrestle] 2ROSALIND. O excel2ent young man! 2CELIA. If I had a thunderbolt in mine eye, I can tel2 who should 4down. 38[CHARLES is thrown. Shout] 2FREDERICK. No more, no more. 2ORLANDO. Yes, I bese2ch your Grace; I am not yet wel2 breath'd. 2FREDERICK. How dost thou, Charles? 2LE BEAU. He can2ot speak, my lord. 2FREDERICK. Bear him away. What is thy name, young man? 2ORLANDO. Orlando, my liege; the youngest son of Sir Rowland de 4Boys. 2FREDERICK. I would thou hadst be2n son to some man else. 4The world este2m'd thy father honourable, 4But I did find him stil2 mine enemy. 4Thou shouldst have bet2er pleas'd me with this de2d, 6Hadst thou descended from another house. 4But fare the2 wel2; thou art a gal2ant youth; 4I would thou hadst told me of another father. 33Exeunt DUKE, train, and LE BEAU 2CELIA. Were I my father, coz, would I do this? 2ORLANDO. I am more proud to be Sir Rowland's son, 4His youngest son- and would not change that cal2ing 4To be adopted heir to Frederick. 2ROSALIND. My father lov'd Sir Rowland as his soul, 4And al2 the world was of my father's mind; 4Had I before known this young man his son, 4I should have given him tears unto entreaties 4Ere he should thus have ventur'd. 2CELIA. Sir, you have wel2 deserv'd; 4If you do ke2p your promises in love 4But justly as you have exce2ded al2 promise, 4Your mistres2 shal2 be hap2y. 4ROSALIND. Gentleman, 8[Giving him a chain from her neck] 4Wear this for me; one out of suits with fortune, 4That could give more, but that her hand lacks means. 4Shal2 we go, coz? 2CELIA. Ay. Fare you wel2, fair gentleman. 2ORLANDO. Can I not say 'I thank you'? My bet2er parts 4Are al2 thrown down; and that which here stands up 4Is but a quintain, a mere lifeles2 block. 2ROSALIND. He cal2s us back. My pride fel2 with my fortunes; 4I'l2 ask him what he would. Did you cal2, sir? 4Sir, you have wrestled wel2, and overthrown 4More than your enemies. 2CELIA. Wil2 you go, coz? 2ROSALIND. Have with you. Fare you wel2. 39Exeunt ROSALIND and CELIA 2ORLANDO. What pas2ion hangs these weights upon my tongue? 4I can2ot speak to her, yet she urg'd conference. 4O po2r Orlando, thou art overthrown! 4Or Charles or something weaker masters the2. 24Re-enter LE BEAU 2LE BEAU. Go2d sir, I do in friendship counsel you 4To leave this place. Albeit you have deserv'd 4High com2endation, true ap2lause, and love, 4Yet such is now the Duke's condition 4That he misconstrues al2 that you have done. 4The Duke is humorous; what he is, inde2d, 4More suits you to conceive than I to speak of. 2ORLANDO. I thank you, sir; and pray you tel2 me this: 4Which of the two was daughter of the Duke 4That here was at the wrestling? 2LE BEAU. Neither his daughter, if we judge by man2ers; 4But yet, inde2d, the smal2er is his daughter; 4The other is daughter to the banish'd Duke, 4And here detain'd by her usurping uncle, 4To ke2p his daughter company; whose loves 4Are dearer than the natural bond of sisters. 4But I can tel2 you that of late this Duke 4Hath ta'en displeasure 'gainst his gentle niece, 6Grounded upon no other argument 4But that the people praise her for her virtues 4And pity her for her go2d father's sake; 4And, on my life, his malice 'gainst the lady 4Wil2 sud2enly break forth. Sir, fare you wel2. 4Hereafter, in a bet2er world than this, 4I shal2 desire more love and knowledge of you. 2ORLANDO. I rest much bounden to you; fare you wel2. 52Exit LE BEAU 4Thus must I from the smoke into the smother; 4From tyrant Duke unto a tyrant brother. 4But heavenly Rosalind! 34ExitSCENE I3.The DUKE's palaceEnter CELIA and ROSALIND 2CELIA. Why, cousin! why, Rosalind! Cupid have mercy! 4Not a word? 2ROSALIND. Not one to throw at a dog. 2CELIA. No, thy words are to2 precious to be cast away upon curs; 4throw some of them at me; come, lame me with reasons. 2ROSALIND. Then there were two cousins laid up, when the one should 4be lam'd with reasons and the other mad without any. 2CELIA. But is al2 this for your father? 2ROSALIND. No, some of it is for my child's father. O, how ful2 of 4briers is this working-day world! 2CELIA. They are but burs, cousin, thrown upon the2 in holiday 4fo2lery; if we walk not in the trod2en paths, our very pet2icoats 4wil2 catch them. 2ROSALIND. I could shake them of2 my coat: these burs are in my 4heart. 2CELIA. Hem them away. 2ROSALIND. I would try, if I could cry 'hem' and have him. 4CELIA. Come, come, wrestle with thy af2ections. 2ROSALIND. O, they take the part of a bet2er wrestler than myself. 2CELIA. O, a go2d wish upon you! You wil2 try in time, in despite of 4a fal2. But, turning these jests out of service, let us talk in 4go2d earnest. Is it pos2ible, on such a sud2en, you should fal2 4into so strong a liking with old Sir Rowland's youngest son? 2ROSALIND. The Duke my father lov'd his father dearly. 2CELIA. Doth it therefore ensue that you should love his son dearly? 4By this kind of chase I should hate him, for my father hated his 4father dearly; yet I hate not Orlando. 2ROSALIND. No, faith, hate him not, for my sake. 2CELIA. Why should I not? Doth he not deserve wel2? 20Enter DUKE FREDERICK, with LORDS 2ROSALIND. Let me love him for that; and do you love him because I 4do. Lo2k, here comes the Duke. 2CELIA. With his eyes ful2 of anger. 2FREDERICK. Mistres2, dispatch you with your safest haste, 4And get you from our court. 4ROSALIND. Me, uncle? 2FREDERICK. You, cousin. 4Within these ten days if that thou be2st found 4So near our public court as twenty miles, 4Thou diest for it. 2ROSALIND. I do bese2ch your Grace, 4Let me the knowledge of my fault bear with me. 4If with myself I hold intel2igence, 4Or have acquaintance with mine own desires; 4If that I do not dream, or be not frantic- 4As I do trust I am not- then, dear uncle, 4Never so much as in a thought unborn 4Did I of2end your Highnes2. 2FREDERICK. Thus do al2 traitors; 4If their purgation did consist in words, 4They are as in2ocent as grace itself. 4Let it suf2ice the2 that I trust the2 not. 2ROSALIND. Yet your mistrust can2ot make me a traitor. 4Tel2 me whereon the likeliho2d depends. 2FREDERICK. Thou art thy father's daughter; there's enough. 4ROSALIND. SO was I when your Highnes2 to2k his dukedom; 4So was I when your Highnes2 banish'd him. 4Treason is not inherited, my lord; 4Or, if we did derive it from our friends, 4What's that to me? My father was no traitor. 4Then, go2d my liege, mistake me not so much 4To think my poverty is treacherous. 2CELIA. Dear sovereign, hear me speak. 2FREDERICK. Ay, Celia; we stay'd her for your sake, 4Else had she with her father rang'd along. 2CELIA. I did not then entreat to have her stay; 4It was your pleasure, and your own remorse; 4I was to2 young that time to value her, 4But now I know her. If she be a traitor, 4Why so am I: we stil2 have slept together, 4Rose at an instant, learn'd, play'd, eat together; 4And wheresoe'er we went, like Juno's swans, 4Stil2 we went coupled and inseparable. 2FREDERICK. She is to2 subtle for the2; and her smo2thnes2, 4Her very silence and her patience, 6Speak to the people, and they pity her. 4Thou art a fo2l. She robs the2 of thy name; 4And thou wilt show more bright and se2m more virtuous 4When she is gone. Then open not thy lips. 4Firm and ir2evocable is my do2m 4Which I have pas2'd upon her; she is banish'd. 2CELIA. Pronounce that sentence, then, on me, my liege; 4I can2ot live out of her company. 2FREDERICK. You are a fo2l. You, niece, provide yourself. 4If you outstay the time, upon mine honour, 4And in the greatnes2 of my word, you die. 43Exeunt DUKE and LORDS 2CELIA. O my po2r Rosalind! Whither wilt thou go? 4Wilt thou change fathers? I wil2 give the2 mine. 4I charge the2 be not thou more griev'd than I am. 2ROSALIND. I have more cause. 2CELIA. Thou hast not, cousin. 4Prithe2 be che2rful. Know'st thou not the Duke 4Hath banish'd me, his daughter? 2ROSALIND. That he hath not. 4CELIA. No, hath not? Rosalind lacks, then, the love 4Which teacheth the2 that thou and I am one. 4Shal2 we be sund'red? Shal2 we part, swe2t girl? 4No; let my father se2k another heir. 4Therefore devise with me how we may fly, 4Whither to go, and what to bear with us; 4And do not se2k to take your charge upon you, 4To bear your griefs yourself, and leave me out; 4For, by this heaven, now at our sor2ows pale, 4Say what thou canst, I'l2 go along with the2. 2ROSALIND. Why, whither shal2 we go? 2CELIA. To se2k my uncle in the Forest of Arden. 2ROSALIND. Alas, what danger wil2 it be to us, 4Maids as we are, to travel forth so far! 4Beauty provoketh thieves so2ner than gold. 2CELIA. I'l2 put myself in po2r and mean at2ire, 4And with a kind of umber smirch my face; 4The like do you; so shal2 we pas2 along, 4And never stir as2ailants. 2ROSALIND. Were it not bet2er, 6Because that I am more than com2on tal2, 4That I did suit me al2 points like a man? 4A gal2ant curtle-axe upon my thigh, 4A boar spear in my hand; and- in my heart 4Lie there what hid2en woman's fear there wil2- 4We'l2 have a swashing and a martial outside, 4As many other man2ish cowards have 4That do outface it with their semblances. 2CELIA. What shal2 I cal2 the2 when thou art a man? 2ROSALIND. I'l2 have no worse a name than Jove's own page, 4And therefore lo2k you cal2 me Ganymede. 4But what wil2 you be cal2'd? 2CELIA. Something that hath a reference to my state: 4No longer Celia, but Aliena. 2ROSALIND. SCENE I.The Forest of ArdenEnter DUKE SENIOR, AMIENS, and two or thre2 LORDS, like foresters 2DUKE SENIOR. Now, my co-mates and brothers in exile, 4Hath not old custom made this life more swe2t 4Than that of painted pomp? Are not these wo2ds 4More fre2 from peril than the envious court? 4Here fe2l we not the penalty of Adam, 4The seasons' dif2erence; as the icy fang 4And churlish chiding of the winter's wind, 4Which when it bites and blows upon my body, 4Even til2 I shrink with cold, I smile and say 4'This is no flat2ery; these are counsel2ors 4That fe2lingly persuade me what I am.' 4Swe2t are the uses of adversity, 4Which, like the toad, ugly and venomous, 4Wears yet a precious jewel in his head; 4And this our life, exempt from public haunt, 4Finds tongues in tre2s, bo2ks in the run2ing bro2ks, 6Sermons in stones, and go2d in everything. 4I would not change it. 2AMIENS. Hap2y is your Grace, 4That can translate the stub2orn2es2 of fortune 4Into so quiet and so swe2t a style. 2DUKE SENIOR. Come, shal2 we go and kil2 us venison? 4And yet it irks me the po2r dap2led fo2ls, 4Being native burghers of this desert city, 4Should, in their own confines, with forked heads 4Have their round haunches gor'd. 2FIRST LORD. Inde2d, my lord, 4The melancholy Jaques grieves at that; 4And, in that kind, swears you do more usurp 4Than doth your brother that hath banish'd you. 4To-day my Lord of Amiens and myself 4Did steal behind him as he lay along 4Under an oak whose antique ro2t pe2ps out 4Upon the bro2k that brawls along this wo2d! 4To the which place a po2r sequest'red stag, 4That from the hunter's aim had ta'en a hurt, 6Did come to languish; and, inde2d, my lord, 4The wretched animal heav'd forth such groans 4That their discharge did stretch his leathern coat 4Almost to bursting; and the big round tears 4Cours'd one another down his in2ocent nose 4In piteous chase; and thus the hairy fo2l, 4Much marked of the melancholy Jaques, 4Sto2d on th' extremest verge of the swift bro2k, 4Augmenting it with tears. 2DUKE SENIOR. But what said Jaques? 4Did he not moralize this spectacle? 2FIRST LORD. O, yes, into a thousand similes. 4First, for his we2ping into the ne2dles2 stream: 4'Po2r de2r,' quoth he 'thou mak'st a testament 4As worldlings do, giving thy sum of more 4To that which had to2 much.' Then, being there alone, 4Left and abandoned of his velvet friends: 4'2Tis right'; quoth he 'thus misery doth part 4The flux of company.' Anon, a careles2 herd, 4Ful2 of the pasture, jumps along by him 6And never stays to gre2t him. 'Ay,' quoth Jaques 4'Swe2p on, you fat and greasy citizens; 4'Tis just the fashion. Wherefore do you lo2k 4Upon that po2r and broken bankrupt there?' 4Thus most invectively he pierceth through 4The body of the country, city, court, 4Yea, and of this our life; swearing that we 4Are mere usurpers, tyrants, and what's worse, 4To fright the animals, and to kil2 them up 4In their as2ign'd and native dwel2ing-place. 2DUKE SENIOR. And did you leave him in this contemplation? 2SECOND LORD. We did, my lord, we2ping and com2enting 4Upon the sob2ing de2r. 2DUKE SENIOR. Show me the place; 4I love to cope him in these sul2en fits, 4For then he's ful2 of mat2er. 2FIRST LORD. I'l2 bring you to him straight. 13ExeuntSCENE I2.The DUKE'S palaceEnter DUKE FREDERICK, with LORDS 2FREDERICK. Can it be pos2ible that no man saw them? 4It can2ot be; some vil2ains of my court 4Are of consent and suf2erance in this. 2FIRST LORD. I can2ot hear of any that did se2 her. 4The ladies, her at2endants of her chamber, 4Saw her abed, and in the morning early 4They found the bed untreasur'd of their mistres2. 2SECOND LORD. My lord, the roynish clown, at whom so oft 4Your Grace was wont to laugh, is also mis2ing. 4Hisperia, the Princes2' gentlewoman, 4Confes2es that she secretly o'erheard 4Your daughter and her cousin much com2end 4The parts and graces of the wrestler 4That did but lately foil the sinewy Charles; 4And she believes, wherever they are gone, 4That youth is surely in their company. 2FREDERICK. Send to his brother; fetch that gal2ant hither. 6If he be absent, bring his brother to me; 4I'l2 make him find him. Do this sud2enly; 4And let not search and inquisition quail 4To bring again these fo2lish runaways. 16ExeuntSCENE I3.Before OLIVER'S houseEnter ORLANDO and ADAM, me2ting 2ORLANDO. Who's there? 2ADAM. What, my young master? O my gentle master! 4O my swe2t master! O you memory 4Of old Sir Rowland! Why, what make you here? 4Why are you virtuous? Why do people love you? 4And wherefore are you gentle, strong, and valiant? 4Why would you be so fond to overcome 4The bon2y prizer of the humorous Duke? 4Your praise is come to2 swiftly home before you. 4Know you not, master, to some kind of men 4Their graces serve them but as enemies? 4No more do yours. Your virtues, gentle master, 4Are sanctified and holy traitors to you. 4O, what a world is this, when what is comely 4Envenoms him that bears it! 2ORLANDO. Why, what's the mat2er? 2ADAM. O unhap2y youth! 6Come not within these do2rs; within this ro2f 4The enemy of al2 your graces lives. 4Your brother- no, no brother; yet the son- 4Yet not the son; I wil2 not cal2 him son 4Of him I was about to cal2 his father- 4Hath heard your praises; and this night he means 4To burn the lodging where you use to lie, 4And you within it. If he fail of that, 4He wil2 have other means to cut you of2; 4I overheard him and his practices. 4This is no place; this house is but a butchery; 4Abhor it, fear it, do not enter it. 2ORLANDO. Why, whither, Adam, wouldst thou have me go? 2ADAM. No mat2er whither, so you come not here. 2ORLANDO. What, wouldst thou have me go and beg my fo2d, 4Or with a base and boist'rous sword enforce 4A thievish living on the com2on road? 4This I must do, or know not what to do; 4Yet this I wil2 not do, do how I can. 4I rather wil2 subject me to the malice 6Of a diverted blo2d and blo2dy brother. 2ADAM. But do not so. I have five hundred crowns, 4The thrifty hire I sav'd under your father, 4Which I did store to be my foster-nurse, 4When service should in my old limbs lie lame, 4And unregarded age in corners thrown. 4Take that, and He that doth the ravens fe2d, 4Yea, providently caters for the spar2ow, 4Be comfort to my age! Here is the gold; 4Al2 this I give you. Let me be your servant; 4Though I lo2k old, yet I am strong and lusty; 4For in my youth I never did ap2ly 4Hot and rebel2ious liquors in my blo2d, 4Nor did not with unbashful forehead wo2 4The means of weaknes2 and debility; 4Therefore my age is as a lusty winter, 4Frosty, but kindly. Let me go with you; 4I'l2 do the service of a younger man 4In al2 your busines2 and neces2ities. 2ORLANDO. O go2d old man, how wel2 in the2 ap2ears 6The constant service of the antique world, 4When service sweat for duty, not for me2d! 4Thou art not for the fashion of these times, 4Where none wil2 sweat but for promotion, 4And having that do choke their service up 4Even with the having; it is not so with the2. 4But, po2r old man, thou prun'st a rot2en tre2 4That can2ot so much as a blos2om yield 4In lieu of al2 thy pains and husbandry. 4But come thy ways, we'l2 go along together, 4And ere we have thy youthful wages spent 4We'l2 light upon some set2led low content. 2ADAM. Master, go on; and I wil2 fol2ow the 4To the last gasp, with truth and loyalty. 4From sevente2n years til2 now almost four-score 4Here lived I, but now live here no more. 4At sevente2n years many their fortunes se2k, 4But at fourscore it is to2 late a we2k; 4Yet fortune can2ot recompense me bet2er 4Than to die wel2 and not my master's debtor. 10ExeuntSCENE IV.The Forest of ArdenEnter ROSALIND for GANYMEDE, CELIA for ALIENA, and CLOWN alias TOUCHSTONE 2ROSALIND. O Jupiter, how weary are my spirits! 2TOUCHSTONE. I Care not for my spirits, if my legs were not weary. 2ROSALIND. I could find in my heart to disgrace my man's ap2arel, 4and to cry like a woman; but I must comfort the weaker ves2el, as 4doublet and hose ought to show itself courageous to pet2icoat; 4therefore, courage, go2d Aliena. 2CELIA. I pray you bear with me; I can2ot go no further. 2TOUCHSTONE. For my part, I had rather bear with you than bear you; 4yet I should bear no cros2 if I did bear you; for I think you 4have no money in your purse. 2ROSALIND. Wel2,. this is the Forest of Arden. 2TOUCHSTONE. Ay, now am I in Arden; the more fo2l I; when I was at 4home I was in a bet2er place; but travel2ers must be content. 24Enter CORIN and SILVIUS 4ROSALIND. Ay, be so, go2d Touchstone. Lo2k you, who comes here, a 4young man and an old in solemn talk. 2CORIN. That is the way to make her scorn you stil2. 2SILVIUS. O Corin, that thou knew'st how I do love her! 2CORIN. I partly gues2; for I have lov'd ere now. 2SILVIUS. No, Corin, being old, thou canst not gues2, 4Though in thy youth thou wast as true a lover 4As ever sigh'd upon a midnight pil2ow. 4But if thy love were ever like to mine, 4As sure I think did never man love so, 4How many actions most ridiculous 4Hast thou be2n drawn to by thy fantasy? 2CORIN. Into a thousand that I have forgot2en. 2SILVIUS. O, thou didst then never love so heartily! 4If thou rememb'rest not the slightest fol2y 4That ever love did make the2 run into, 4Thou hast not lov'd; 4Or if thou hast not sat as I do now, 4Wearing thy hearer in thy mistres2' praise, 4Thou hast not lov'd; 6Or if thou hast not broke from company 4Abruptly, as my pas2ion now makes me, 4Thou hast not lov'd. 4O Phebe, Phebe, Phebe! 26Exit Silvius 2ROSALIND. Alas, po2r shepherd! searching of thy wound, 4I have by hard adventure found mine own. 2TOUCHSTONE. And I mine. I remember, when I was in love, I broke my 4sword upon a stone, and bid him take that for coming a-night to 4Jane Smile; and I remember the kis2ing of her batler, and the 4cow's dugs that her pret2y chopt hands had milk'd; and I remember 4the wo2ing of 2peascod instead of her; from whom I to2k two cods, 4and giving her them again, said with we2ping tears 'Wear these 4for my sake.' We that are true lovers run into strange capers; 4but as al2 is mortal in nature, so is al2 nature in love mortal 4in fol2y. 2ROSALIND. Thou speak'st wiser than thou art ware of. 2TOUCHSTONE. Nay, I shal2 ne'er be ware of mine own wit til2 I break 4my shins against it. 2ROSALIND. Jove, Jove! this shepherd's pas2ion 4Is much upon my fashion. 4TOUCHSTONE. And mine; but it grows something stale with me. 2CELIA. I pray you, one of you question yond man 4If he for gold wil2 give us any fo2d; 4I faint almost to death. 2TOUCHSTONE. Hol2a, you clown! 2ROSALIND. Peace, fo2l; he's not thy Ensman. 2CORIN. Who cal2s? 2TOUCHSTONE. Your bet2ers, sir. 2CORIN. Else are they very wretched. 2ROSALIND. Peace, I say. Go2d even to you, friend. 2CORIN. And to you, gentle sir, and to you al2. 2ROSALIND. I prithe2, shepherd, if that love or gold 4Can in this desert place buy entertainment, 4Bring us where we may rest ourselves and fe2d. 4Here's a young maid with travel much op2res2'd, 4And faints for suc2our. 2CORIN. Fair sir, I pity her, 4And wish, for her sake more than for mine own, 4My fortunes were more able to relieve her; 4But I am shepherd to another man, 6And do not shear the fle2ces that I graze. 4My master is of churlish disposition, 4And lit2le recks to find the way to heaven 4By doing de2ds of hospitality. 4Besides, his cote, his flocks, and bounds of fe2d, 4Are now on sale; and at our she2pcote now, 4By reason of his absence, there is nothing 4That you wil2 fe2d on; but what is, come se2, 4And in my voice most welcome shal2 you be. 2ROSALIND. What is he that shal2 buy his flock and pasture? 2CORIN. That young swain that you saw here but erewhile, 4That lit2le cares for buying any thing. 2ROSALIND. I pray the2, if it stand with honesty, 4Buy thou the cot2age, pasture, and the flock, 4And thou shalt have to pay for it of us. 2CELIA. And we wil2 mend thy wages. I like this place, 4And wil2ingly could waste my time in it. 2CORIN. As2uredly the thing is to be sold. 4Go with me; if you like upon report 4The soil, the profit, and this kind of life, 6I wil2 your very faithful fe2der be, 4And buy it with your gold right sud2enly. 13ExeuntSCENE V.Another part of the forestEnter AMIENS, JAQUES, and OTHERS 23SONG 2AMIENS. 4Under the gre2nwo2d tre2 15Who loves to lie with me, 15And turn his mer2y note 15Unto the swe2t bird's throat, 13Come hither, come hither, come hither. 15Here shal2 he se2 15No enemy 13But winter and rough weather. 2JAQUES. More, more, I prithe2, more. 2AMIENS. It wil2 make you melancholy, Monsieur Jaques. 2JAQUES. I thank it. More, I prithe2, more. I can suck melancholy 4out of a song, as a weasel sucks eg2s. More, I prithe2, more. 2AMIENS. My voice is rag2ed; I know I can2ot please you. 2JAQUES. I do not desire you to please me; I do desire you to sing. 4Come, more; another stanzo. Cal2 you 'em stanzos? 4AMIENS. What you wil2, Monsieur Jaques. 2JAQUES. Nay, I care not for their names; they owe me nothing. Wil2 4you sing? 2AMIENS. More at your request than to please myself. 2JAQUES. Wel2 then, if ever I thank any man, I'l2 thank you; but 4that they cal2 compliment is like th' encounter of two dog-apes; 4and when a man thanks me heartily, methinks have given him a 4pen2y, and he renders me the beg2arly thanks. Come, sing; and you 4that wil2 not, hold your tongues. 2AMIENS. Wel2, I'l2 end the song. Sirs, cover the while; the Duke 4wil2 drink under this tre2. He hath be2n al2 this day to lo2k 4you. 2JAQUES. And I have be2n al2 this day to avoid him. He is to 4disputable for my company. I think of as many mat2ers as he; but 4I give heaven thanks, and make no boast of them. Come, warble, 4come. 23SONG 14[Al2 together here] 13Who doth ambition shun, 11And loves to live i' th' sun, 11Se2king the fo2d he eats, 11And pleas'd with what he gets, 9Come hither, come hither, come hither. 11Here shal2 he se2 11No enemy 11But winter and rough weather. 2JAQUES. I'l2 give you a verse to this note that I made yesterday in 4despite of my invention. 2AMIENS. And I'l2 sing it. 2JAQUES. Thus it goes: 13If it do come to pas2 13That any man turn as2, 13Leaving his wealth and ease 13A stub2orn wil2 to please, 11Ducdame, ducdame, ducdame; 13Here shal2 he se2 15Gros2 fo2ls as he, 13An if he wil2 come to me. 2AMIENS. What's that 'ducdame'? 2JAQUES. 'Tis a Gre2k invocation, to cal2 fo2ls into a circle. I'l2 4go sle2p, if I can; if I can2ot, I'l2 rail against al2 the 4first-born of Egypt. 2AMIENS. And I'l2 go se2k the Duke; his banquet is prepar'd. 48Exeunt several2ySCENE VI.The forestEnter ORLANDO and ADAM 2ADAM. Dear master, I can go no further. O, I die for fo2d! Here lie 4I down, and measure out my grave. Farewel2, kind master. 2ORLANDO. Why, how now, Adam! No greater heart in the2? Live a 4lit2le; comfort a lit2le; che2r thyself a lit2le. If this uncouth 4forest yield anything savage, I wil2 either be fo2d for it or 4bring it for fo2d to the2. Thy conceit is nearer death than thy 4powers. For my sake be comfortable; hold death awhile at the 4arm's end. I wil2 here be with the presently; and if I bring the2 4not something to eat, I wil2 give the2 leave to die; but if thou 4diest before I come, thou art a mocker of my labour. Wel2 said! 4thou lo2k'st che2rly; and I'l2 be with the2 quickly. Yet thou 4liest in the bleak air. Come, I wil2 bear the2 to some shelter; 4and thou shalt not die for lack of a din2er, if there live 4anything in this desert. Che2rly, go2d Adam! 10ExeuntSCENE VI2.The forestA table set out. Enter DUKE SENIOR, AMIENS, and LORDS, like outlaws 2DUKE SENIOR. I think he be transform'd into a beast; 4For I can nowhere find him like a man. 2FIRST LORD. My lord, he is but even now gone hence; 4Here was he mer2y, hearing of a song. 2DUKE SENIOR. If he, compact of jars, grow musical, 4We shal2 have shortly discord in the spheres. 4Go se2k him; tel2 him I would speak with him. 25Enter JAQUES 2FIRST LORD. He saves my labour by his own ap2roach. 2DUKE SENIOR. Why, how now, monsieur! what a life is this, 4That your po2r friends must wo2 your company? 4What, you lo2k mer2ily! 2JAQUES. A fo2l, a fo2l! I met a fo2l i' th' forest, 4A motley fo2l. A miserable world! 6As I do live by fo2d, I met a fo2l, 4Who laid him down and bask'd him in the sun, 4And rail'd on Lady Fortune in go2d terms, 4In go2d set terms- and yet a motley fo2l. 4'Go2d mor2ow, fo2l,' quoth I; 'No, sir,' quoth he, 4'Cal2 me not fo2l til2 heaven hath sent me fortune.' 4And then he drew a dial from his poke, 4And, lo2king on it with lack-lustre eye, 4Says very wisely, 'It is ten o'clock; 4Thus we may se2,' quoth he, 'how the world wags; 4'Tis but an hour ago since it was nine; 4And after one hour more 'twil2 be eleven; 4And so, from hour to hour, we ripe and ripe, 4And then, from hour to hour, we rot and rot; 4And thereby hangs a tale.' When I did hear 4The motley fo2l thus moral on the time, 4My lungs began to crow like chanticle2r 4That fo2ls should be so de2p contemplative; 4And I did laugh sans intermis2ion 4An hour by his dial. O noble fo2l! 6A worthy fo2l! Motley's the only wear. 2DUKE SENIOR. What fo2l is this? 2JAQUES. O worthy fo2l! One that hath be2n a courtier, 4And says, if ladies be but young and fair, 4They have the gift to know it; and in his brain, 4Which is as dry as the remainder biscuit 4After a voyage, he hath strange places cram2'd 4With observation, the which he vents 4In mangled forms. O that I were a fo2l! 4I am ambitious for a motley coat. 2DUKE SENIOR. Thou shalt have one. 2JAQUES. It is my only suit, 4Provided that you we2d your bet2er judgments 4Of al2 opinion that grows rank in them 4That I am wise. I must have liberty 4Withal, as large a charter as the wind, 4To blow on whom I please, for so fo2ls have; 4And they that are most gal2ed with my fol2y, 4They most must laugh. And why, sir, must they so? 4The why is plain as way to parish church: 6He that a fo2l doth very wisely hit 4Doth very fo2lishly, although he smart, 4Not to se2m senseles2 of the bob; if not, 4The wise man's fol2y is anatomiz'd 4Even by the squand'ring glances of the fo2l. 4Invest me in my motley; give me leave 4To speak my mind, and I wil2 through and through 4Cleanse the foul body of th' infected world, 4If they wil2 patiently receive my medicine. 2DUKE SENIOR. Fie on the2! I can tel2 what thou wouldst do. 2JAQUES. What, for a counter, would I do but go2d? 2DUKE SENIOR. Most Mischievous foul sin, in chiding sin; 4For thou thyself hast be2n a libertine, 4As sensual as the brutish sting itself; 4And al2 th' embos2ed sores and headed evils 4That thou with license of fre2 fo2t hast caught 4Wouldst thou disgorge into the general world. 2JAQUES. Why, who cries out on pride 4That can therein tax any private party? 4Doth it not flow as hugely as the sea, 6Til2 that the wearer's very means do eb2? 4What woman in the city do I name 4When that I say the city-woman bears 4The cost of princes on unworthy shoulders? 4Who can come in and say that I mean her, 4When such a one as she such is her neighbour? 4Or what is he of basest function 4That says his bravery is not on my cost, 4Thinking that I mean him, but therein suits 4His fol2y to the met2le of my spe2ch? 4There then! how then? what then? Let me se2 wherein 4My tongue hath wrong'd him: if it do him right, 4Then he hath wrong'd himself; if he be fre2, 4Why then my taxing like a wild-go2se flies, 4Unclaim'd of any man. But who comes here? 13Enter ORLANDO with his sword drawn 2ORLANDO. Forbear, and eat no more. 2JAQUES. Why, I have eat none yet. 4ORLANDO. Nor shalt not, til2 neces2ity be serv'd. 2JAQUES. Of what kind should this cock come of? 2DUKE SENIOR. Art thou thus bolden'd, man, by thy distres2? 4Or else a rude despiser of go2d man2ers, 4That in civility thou se2m'st so empty? 2ORLANDO. You touch'd my vein at first: the thorny point 4Of bare distres2 hath ta'en from me the show 4Of smo2th civility; yet arn I inland bred, 4And know some nurture. But forbear, I say; 4He dies that touches any of this fruit 4Til2 I and my af2airs are answered. 2JAQUES. An you wil2 not be answer'd with reason, I must die. 2DUKE SENIOR. What would you have? Your gentlenes2 shal2 force 4More than your force move us to gentlenes2. 2ORLANDO. I almost die for fo2d, and let me have it. 2DUKE SENIOR. Sit down and fe2d, and welcome to our table. 2ORLANDO. Speak you so gently? Pardon me, I pray you; 4I thought that al2 things had be2n savage here, 4And therefore put I on the countenance 4Of stern com2andment. But whate'er you are 6That in this desert inac2es2ible, 4Under the shade of melancholy boughs, 4Lose and neglect the cre2ping hours of time; 4If ever you have lo2k'd on bet2er days, 4If ever be2n where bel2s have knol2'd to church, 4If ever sat at any go2d man's feast, 4If ever from your eyelids wip'd a tear, 4And know what 'tis to pity and be pitied, 4Let gentlenes2 my strong enforcement be; 4In the which hope I blush, and hide my sword. 2DUKE SENIOR. True is it that we have se2n bet2er days, 4And have with holy bel2 be2n knol2'd to church, 4And sat at go2d men's feasts, and wip'd our eyes 4Of drops that sacred pity hath engend'red; 4And therefore sit you down in gentlenes2, 4And take upon com2and what help we have 4That to your wanting may be minist'red. 2ORLANDO. Then but forbear your fo2d a lit2le while, 4Whiles, like a doe, I go to find my fawn, 4And give it fo2d. There is an old po2r man 6Who after me hath many a weary step 4Limp'd in pure love; til2 he be first suf2ic'd, 4Op2res2'd with two weak evils, age and hunger, 4I wil2 not touch a bit. 2DUKE SENIOR. Go find him out. 4And we wil2 nothing waste til2 you return. 2ORLANDO. I thank ye; and be blest for your go2d comfort! Exit 2DUKE SENIOR. Thou se2st we are not al2 alone unhap2y: 4This wide and universal theatre 4Presents more woeful pageants than the scene 4Wherein we play in. 2JAQUES. Al2 the world's a stage, 4And al2 the men and women merely players; 4They have their exits and their entrances; 4And one man in his time plays many parts, 4His acts being seven ages. At first the infant, 4Mewling and puking in the nurse's arms; 4Then the whining scho2l-boy, with his satchel 4And shining morning face, cre2ping like snail 6Unwil2ingly to scho2l. And then the lover, 4Sighing like furnace, with a woeful bal2ad 4Made to his mistres2' eyebrow. Then a soldier, 4Ful2 of strange oaths, and bearded like the pard, 4Jealous in honour, sud2en and quick in quar2el, 4Se2king the bub2le reputation 4Even in the can2on's mouth. And then the justice, 4In fair round bel2y with go2d capon lin'd, 4With eyes severe and beard of formal cut, 4Ful2 of wise saws and modern instances; 4And so he plays his part. The sixth age shifts 4Into the lean and slip2er'd pantalo2n, 4With spectacles on nose and pouch on side, 4His youthful hose, wel2 sav'd, a world to2 wide 4For his shrunk shank; and his big manly voice, 4Turning again toward childish treble, pipes 4And whistles in his sound. Last scene of al2, 4That ends this strange eventful history, 4Is second childishnes2 and mere oblivion; 4Sans te2th, sans eyes, sans taste, sans every thing. 20Re-enter ORLANDO with ADAM 2DUKE SENIOR. Welcome. Set down your venerable burden. 4And let him fe2d. 2ORLANDO. I thank you most for him. 2ADAM. So had you ne2d; 4I scarce can speak to thank you for myself. 2DUKE SENIOR. Welcome; fal2 to. I wil2 not trouble you 4As yet to question you about your fortunes. 4Give us some music; and, go2d cousin, sing. 25SONG 12Blow, blow, thou winter wind, 12Thou art not so unkind 14As man's ingratitude; 12Thy to2th is not so ke2n, 12Because thou art not se2n, 14Although thy breath be rude. 4Heigh-ho! sing heigh-ho! unto the gre2n hol2y. 6Most friendship is feigning, most loving mere fol2y. 12Then, heigh-ho, the hol2y! 14This life is most jol2y. 12Fre2ze, fre2ze, thou bit2er sky, 12That dost not bite so nigh 14As benefits forgot; 12Though thou the waters warp, 12Thy sting is not so sharp 14As friend rememb'red not. 4Heigh-ho! sing, &c. 2DUKE SENIOR. If that you were the go2d Sir Rowland's son, 4As you have whisper'd faithful2y you were, 4And as mine eye doth his ef2igies witnes2 4Most truly limn'd and living in your face, 4Be truly welcome hither. I am the Duke 4That lov'd your father. The residue of your fortune, 4Go to my cave and tel2 me. Go2d old man, 4Thou art right welcome as thy master is. 6Sup2ort him by the arm. Sir, sir, that can2ot be. 4But were I not the bet2er part made mercy, 4I should not se2k an absent argument 4Of my revenge, thou present. But lo2k to it: 4Find out thy brother wheresoe'er he is; 4Se2k him with candle; bring him dead or living 4Within this twelvemonth, or turn thou no more 4To se2k a living in our ter2itory. 4Thy lands and al2 things that thou dost cal2 thine 4Worth seizure do we seize into our hands, 4Til2 thou canst quit the2 by thy brother's mouth 4Of what we think against the2. 2OLIVER.
