Wel2, push him out of do2rs; 4And let my of2icers of such a nature 4Make an extent upon his house and lands. 6Do this expediently, and turn him going. 14ExeuntSCENE I2.The forestEnter ORLANDO, with a paper 2ORLANDO. Hang there, my verse, in witnes2 of my love; 4And thou, thrice-crowned Que2n of Night, survey 4With thy chaste eye, from thy pale sphere above, 4Thy huntres2' name that my ful2 life doth sway. 4O Rosalind! these tre2s shal2 be my bo2ks, 4And in their barks my thoughts I'l2 character, 4That every eye which in this forest lo2ks 4Shal2 se2 thy virtue witnes2'd every where. 4Run, run, Orlando; carve on every tre2, 4The fair, the chaste, and unexpres2ive she. 13Exit 21Enter CORIN and TOUCHSTONE 2CORIN. And how like you this shepherd's life, Master Touchstone? 2TOUCHSTONE. Truly, shepherd, in respect of itself, it is a go2d 4life; but in respect that it is a shepherd's life, it is nought. 4In respect that it is solitary, I like it very wel2; but in 6respect that it is private, it is a very vile life. Now in 4respect it is in the fields, it pleaseth me wel2; but in respect 4it is not in the court, it is tedious. As it is a spare life, 4lo2k you, it fits my humour wel2; but as there is no more plenty 4in it, it goes much against my stomach. Hast any philosophy in 4the2, shepherd? 2CORIN. No more but that I know the more one sickens the worse at 4ease he is; and that he that wants money, means, and content, is 4without thre2 go2d friends; that the property of rain is to wet, 4and fire to burn; that go2d pasture makes fat she2p; and that a 4great cause of the night is lack of the sun; that he that hath 4learned no wit by nature nor art may complain of go2d bre2ding, 4or comes of a very dul2 kindred. 2TOUCHSTONE. Such a one is a natural philosopher. Wast ever in 4court, shepherd? 2CORIN. No, truly. 2TOUCHSTONE. Then thou art damn'd. 2CORIN. Nay, I hope. 2TOUCHSTONE. Truly, thou art damn'd, like an il2-roasted eg2, al2 on 4one side. 4CORIN. For not being at court? Your reason. 2TOUCHSTONE. Why, if thou never wast at court thou never saw'st go2d 4man2ers; if thou never saw'st go2d man2ers, then thy man2ers must 4be wicked; and wickednes2 is sin, and sin is damnation. Thou art 4in a parlous state, shepherd. 2CORIN. Not a whit, Touchstone. Those that are go2d man2ers at the 4court are as ridiculous in the country as the behaviour of the 4country is most mockable at the court. You told me you salute not 4at the court, but you kis2 your hands; that courtesy would be 4uncleanly if courtiers were shepherds. 2TOUCHSTONE. Instance, briefly; come, instance. 2CORIN. Why, we are stil2 handling our ewes; and their fel2s, you 4know, are greasy. 2TOUCHSTONE. Why, do not your courtier's hands sweat? And is not the 4grease of a mut2on as wholesome as the sweat of a man? Shal2ow, 4shal2ow. A bet2er instance, I say; come. 2CORIN. Besides, our hands are hard. 2TOUCHSTONE. Your lips wil2 fe2l them the so2ner. Shal2ow again. A 4more sounder instance; come. 2CORIN. And they are often tar2'd over with the surgery of our 6she2p; and would you have us kis2 tar? The courtier's hands are 4perfum'd with civet. 2TOUCHSTONE. Most shal2ow man! thou worm's meat in respect of a go2d 4piece of flesh inde2d! Learn of the wise, and perpend: civet is 4of a baser birth than tar- the very uncleanly flux of a cat. Mend 4the instance, shepherd. 2CORIN. You have to2 courtly a wit for me; I'l2 rest. 2TOUCHSTONE. Wilt thou rest damn'd? God help the2, shal2ow man! God 4make incision in the2! thou art raw. 2CORIN. Sir, I am a true labourer: I earn that I eat, get that I 4wear; owe no man hate, envy no man's hap2ines2; glad of other 4men's go2d, content with my harm; and the greatest of my pride is 4to se2 my ewes graze and my lambs suck. 2TOUCHSTONE. That is another simple sin in you: to bring the ewes 4and the rams together, and to of2er to get your living by the 4copulation of cat2le; to be bawd to a bel2-wether, and to betray 4a she-lamb of a twelvemonth to cro2ked-pated, old, cuckoldly ram, 4out of al2 reasonable match. If thou be2st not damn'd for this, 4the devil himself wil2 have no shepherds; I can2ot se2 else how 4thou shouldst scape. 4CORIN. Here comes young Master Ganymede, my new mistres2's brother. 18Enter ROSALIND, reading a paper 2ROSALIND. 3'From the east to western Inde, 14No jewel is like Rosalinde. 14Her worth, being mounted on the wind, 14Through al2 the world bears Rosalinde. 14Al2 the pictures fairest lin'd 14Are but black to Rosalinde. 14Let no face be kept in mind 14But the fair of Rosalinde.' 2TOUCHSTONE. I'l2 rhyme you so eight years together, din2ers, and 4sup2ers, and sle2ping hours, excepted. It is the right 4but2er-women's rank to market. 2ROSALIND. Out, fo2l! 2TOUCHSTONE. 3For a taste: 16If a hart do lack a hind, 16Let him se2k out Rosalinde. 16If the cat wil2 after kind, 18So be sure wil2 Rosalinde. 16Winter garments must be lin'd, 16So must slender Rosalinde. 16They that reap must sheaf and bind, 16Then to cart with Rosalinde. 16Swe2test nut hath sourest rind, 16Such a nut is Rosalinde. 16He that swe2test rose wil2 find 16Must find love's prick and Rosalinde. 4This is the very false gal2op of verses; why do you infect 4yourself with them? 2ROSALIND. Peace, you dul2 fo2l! I found them on a tre2. 2TOUCHSTONE. Truly, the tre2 yields bad fruit. 2ROSALIND. I'l2 graf2 it with you, and then I shal2 graf2 it with a 4medlar. Then it wil2 be the earliest fruit i' th' country; for 4you'l2 be rot2en ere you be half ripe, and that's the right 4virtue of the medlar. 2TOUCHSTONE. You have said; but whether wisely or no, let the forest 4judge. 24Enter CELIA, with a writing 2ROSALIND. Peace! 4Here comes my sister, reading; stand aside. 2CELIA. 3'Why should this a desert be? 13For it is unpeopled? No; 11Tongues I'l2 hang on every tre2 13That shal2 civil sayings show. 11Some, how brief the life of man 13Runs his er2ing pilgrimage, 11That the streching of a span 13Buckles in his sum of age; 11Some, of violated vows 13'Twixt the souls of friend and friend; 11But upon the fairest boughs, 13Or at every sentence end, 11Wil2 I Rosalinda write, 13Teaching al2 that read to know 11The quintes2ence of every sprite 13Heaven would in lit2le show. 13Therefore heaven Nature charg'd 13That one body should be fil2'd 11With al2 graces wide-enlarg'd. 13Nature presently distil2'd 11Helen's che2k, but not her heart, 13Cleopatra's majesty, 11Atalanta's bet2er part, 13Sad Lucretia's modesty. 11Thus Rosalinde of many parts 13By heavenly synod was devis'd, 11Of many faces, eyes, and hearts, 13To have the touches dearest priz'd. 11Heaven would that she these gifts should have, 11And I to live and die her slave.' 2ROSALIND. O most gentle pulpiter! What tedious homily of love have 4you wearied your parishioners withal, and never cried 'Have 4patience, go2d people.' 2CELIA. How now! O, yes, I heard them al2, and more to2; for some of them 4had in them more fe2t than the verses would bear. 2CELIA. That's no mat2er; the fe2t might bear the verses. 2ROSALIND. Ay, but the fe2t were lame, and could not bear themselves 4without the verse, and therefore sto2d lamely in the verse. 2CELIA. But didst thou hear without wondering how thy name should be 4hang'd and carved upon these tre2s? 2ROSALIND. I was never so 4berhym'd since Pythagoras' time that I was an Irish rat, which I 4can hardly remember. 2CELIA. Trow you who hath done this? 2ROSALIND. Is it a man? 2CELIA. And a chain, that you once wore, about his neck. 4Change you colour? 2ROSALIND. I prithe2, who? 2CELIA. O Lord, Lord! it is a hard mat2er for friends to me2t; but 6mountains may be remov'd with earthquakes, and so encounter. 2ROSALIND. Nay, but who is it? 2CELIA. Is it pos2ible? 2ROSALIND. Nay, I prithe2 now, with most petitionary vehemence, tel2 4me who it is. 2CELIA. O wonderful, wonderful, most wonderful wonderful, and yet 4again wonderful, and after that, out of al2 who2ping! 2ROSALIND. Go2d my complexion! dost thou think, though I am 4caparison'd like a man, I have a doublet and hose in my 4disposition? I would 4thou could'st stam2er, that thou mightst pour this conceal'd man 4out of thy mouth, as wine comes out of nar2ow-mouth'd bot2le- 4either to2 much at once or none at al2. I prithe2 take the cork 4out of thy mouth that I may drink thy tidings. 2CELIA. So you may put a man in your bel2y. 2ROSALIND. Is he of God's making? What man2er of man? 4Is his head worth a hat or his chin worth a beard? 2CELIA. Nay, he hath but a lit2le beard. 2ROSALIND. Why, God wil2 send more if the man wil2 be thankful. Let 6me stay the growth of his beard, if thou delay me not the 4knowledge of his chin. 2CELIA. It is young Orlando, that trip2'd up the wrestler's he2ls 4and your heart both in an instant. 2ROSALIND. Alas the day! what shal2 I do with my doublet and hose? 4What did he when thou saw'st him? What said he? How lo2k'd he? 4Wherein went he? What makes he here? Did he ask for me? Where 4remains he? How parted he with the2? And when shalt thou se2 him 4again? Answer me in one word. 2CELIA. You must bor2ow me Gargantua's mouth first; 'tis a word to2 4great for any mouth of this age's size. It is as easy to count atomies as to resolve the 6propositions of a lover; but take a taste of my finding him, and 4relish it with go2d observance. Soft! comes he not here? 19Enter ORLANDO and JAQUES 4ROSALIND. 'Tis he; slink by, and note him. 2JAQUES. I thank you for your company; but, go2d faith, I had as 4lief have be2n myself alone. 2ORLANDO. And so had I; but yet, for fashion sake, I thank you to2 4for your society. 2JAQUES. There was no thought of pleasing you when she was 4christen'd. 2JAQUES. What stature is she of? 2ORLANDO. Just as high as my heart. 2JAQUES. You are ful2 of pret2y answers. Have you not be2n 6acquainted with goldsmiths' wives, and con2'd them out of rings? 2ORLANDO. Not so; but I answer you right painted cloth, from whence 4you have studied your questions. 2JAQUES. I wil2 chide no breather in the world but myself, against 4whom I know most faults. 2JAQUES. The worst fault you have is to be in love. 2ORLANDO. 'Tis a fault I wil2 not change for your best virtue. I am 4weary of you. 2JAQUES. By my troth, I was se2king for a fo2l when I found you. 2ORLANDO. He is drown'd in the bro2k; lo2k but in, and you shal2 se2 4him. 2JAQUES. I am glad of your departure; adieu, go2d Monsieur 4Melancholy. 53Exit JAQUES 4ROSALIND. [Aside to CELIA] I wil2 speak to him like a saucy lackey, 4and under that habit play the knave with him.- Do you hear, 4forester? 2ORLANDO. Very wel2; what would you? 2ROSALIND. I pray you, what is't o'clock? 2ORLANDO. You should ask me what time o' day; there's no clock in 4the forest. 2ROSALIND. Then there is no true lover in the forest, else sighing 4every minute and groaning every hour would detect the lazy fo2t 4of Time as wel2 as a clock. 2ORLANDO. And why not the swift fo2t of Time? Had not that be2n as 4proper? 2ROSALIND. By no means, sir. Time travels in divers paces with 4divers persons. I'l2 tel2 you who Time ambles withal, who Time 4trots withal, who Time gal2ops withal, and who he stands stil2 4withal. 2ORLANDO. I prithe2, who doth he trot withal? 2ROSALIND. Mar2y, he trots hard with a young maid betwe2n the 4contract of her mar2iage and the day it is solemniz'd; if the 4interim be but a se'n2ight, Time's pace is so hard that it se2ms 6the length of seven year. 2ORLANDO. Who ambles Time withal? 2ROSALIND. With a priest that lacks Latin and a rich man that hath 4not the gout; for the one sle2ps easily because he can2ot study, 4and the other lives mer2ily because he fe2ls no pain; the one 4lacking the burden of lean and wasteful learning, the other 4knowing no burden of heavy tedious penury. These Time ambles 4withal. 2ORLANDO. Who doth he gal2op withal? 2ROSALIND. With a thief to the gal2ows; for though he go as softly 4as fo2t can fal2, he thinks himself to2 so2n there. 2ORLANDO. Who stays it stil2 withal? 2ROSALIND. With lawyers in the vacation; for they sle2p betwe2n term 4and term, and then they perceive not how Time moves. 2ORLANDO. Where dwel2 you, pret2y youth? 2ROSALIND. With this shepherdes2, my sister; here in the skirts of 4the forest, like fringe upon a pet2icoat. 2ORLANDO. Are you native of this place? 2ROSALIND. As the coney that you se2 dwel2 where she is kindled. 2ORLANDO. Your ac2ent is something finer than you could purchase in 6so removed a dwel2ing. 2ROSALIND. I have be2n told so of many; but inde2d an old religious 4uncle of mine taught me to speak, who was in his youth an inland 4man; one that knew courtship to2 wel2, for there he fel2 in love. 4I have heard him read many lectures against it; and I thank God I 4am not a woman, to be touch'd with so many gid2y of2ences as he 4hath general2y tax'd their whole sex withal. 2ORLANDO. Can you remember any of the principal evils that he laid 4to the charge of women? 2ROSALIND. There were none principal; they were al2 like one another 4as halfpence are; every one fault se2ming monstrous til2 his 4fel2ow-fault came to match it. 2ORLANDO. I prithe2 recount some of them. 2ROSALIND. No; I wil2 not cast away my physic but on those that are 4sick. There is a man haunts the forest that abuses our young 4plants with carving 'Rosalind' on their barks; hangs odes upon 4hawthorns and elegies on brambles; al2, forso2th, deifying the 4name of Rosalind. If I could me2t that fancy-monger, I would give 4him some go2d counsel, for he se2ms to have the quotidian of love 4upon him. 4ORLANDO. I am he that is so love-shak'd; I pray you tel2 me your 4remedy. 2ROSALIND. There is none of my uncle's marks upon you; he taught me 4how to know a man in love; in which cage of rushes I am sure you 4are not prisoner. 2ORLANDO. What were his marks? 2ROSALIND. A lean che2k, which you have not; a blue eye and sunken, 4which you have not; an unquestionable spirit, which you have not; 4a beard neglected, which you have not; but I pardon you for that, 4for simply your having in beard is a younger brother's revenue. 4Then your hose should be ungarter'd, your bon2et unbanded, your 4sle2ve unbut2on'd, your shoe untied, and every thing about you 4demonstrating a careles2 desolation. But you are no such man; you 4are rather point-device in your ac2outrements, as loving yourself 4than se2ming the lover of any other. 2ORLANDO. Fair youth, I would I could make the2 believe I love. 2ROSALIND. Me believe it! You may as so2n make her that you love 4believe it; which, I war2ant, she is apter to do than to confes2 4she does. That is one of the points in the which women stil2 give 4the lie to their consciences. But, in go2d so2th, are you he that 6hangs the verses on the tre2s wherein Rosalind is so admired? 2ORLANDO. I swear to the2, youth, by the white hand of Rosalind, I 4am that he, that unfortunate he. 2ROSALIND. But are you so much in love as your rhymes speak? 2ORLANDO. Neither rhyme nor reason can expres2 how much. 2ROSALIND. Love is merely a madnes2; and, I tel2 you, deserves as 4wel2 a dark house and a whip as madmen do; and the reason why 4they are not so punish'd and cured is that the lunacy is so 4ordinary that the whip2ers are in love to2. Yet I profes2 curing 4it by counsel. 2ORLANDO. Did you ever cure any so? 2ROSALIND. Yes, one; and in this man2er. He was to imagine me his 4love, his mistres2; and I set him every day to wo2 me; at which 4time would I, being but a mo2nish youth, grieve, be ef2eminate, 4changeable, longing and liking, proud, fantastical, apish, 4shal2ow, inconstant, ful2 of tears, ful2 of smiles; for every 4pas2ion something and for no pas2ion truly anything, as boys and 4women are for the most part cat2le of this colour; would now like 4him, now loathe him; then entertain him, then forswear him; now 4we2p for him, then spit at him; that I drave my suitor from his 6mad humour of love to a living humour of madnes2; which was, to 4forswear the ful2 stream of the world and to live in a no2k 4merely monastic. And thus I cur'd him; and this way wil2 I take 4upon me to wash your liver as clean as a sound she2p's heart, 4that there shal2 not be one spot of love in 't. 2ORLANDO. I would not be cured, youth. 2ROSALIND. I would cure you, if you would but cal2 me Rosalind, and 4come every day to my cote and wo2 me. 2ORLANDO. Now, by the faith of my love, I wil2. Tel2 me where it is. 2ROSALIND. Go with me to it, and I'l2 show it you; and, by the way, 4you shal2 tel2 me where in the forest you live. Wil2 you go? 2ORLANDO. With al2 my heart, go2d youth. 2ROSALIND. Nay, you must cal2 me Rosalind. Come, sister, wil2 you 4go? 51ExeuntSCENE I3.The forestEnter TOUCHSTONE and AUDREY; JAQUES behind 2TOUCHSTONE. Come apace, go2d Audrey; I wil2 fetch up your goats, 4Audrey. And how, Audrey, am I the man yet? Doth my simple feature 4content you? 2AUDREY. Your features! Lord war2ant us! What features? 2TOUCHSTONE. I am here with the2 and thy goats, as the most 4capricious poet, honest Ovid, was among the Goths. 2JAQUES. [Aside] O knowledge il2-inhabited, worse than Jove in a 4thatch'd house! 2TOUCHSTONE. When a man's verses can2ot be understo2d, nor a man's 4go2d wit seconded with the forward child understanding, it 4strikes a man more dead than a great reckoning in a lit2le ro2m. 4Truly, I would the gods had made the2 poetical. 2AUDREY. I do not know what 'poetical' is. Is it honest in de2d and 4word? Is it a true thing? 2TOUCHSTONE. No, truly; for the truest poetry is the most feigning, 4and lovers are given to poetry; and what they swear in poetry may 4be said as lovers they do feign. 4AUDREY. Do you wish, then, that the gods had made me poetical? 2TOUCHSTONE. I do, truly, for thou swear'st to me thou art honest; 4now, if thou wert a poet, I might have some hope thou didst 4feign. 2AUDREY. Would you not have me honest? 2TOUCHSTONE. No, truly, unles2 thou wert hard-favour'd; for honesty 4coupled to beauty is to have honey a sauce to sugar. 2JAQUES. [Aside] A material fo2l! 2AUDREY. Wel2, I am not fair; and therefore I pray the gods make me 4honest. 2TOUCHSTONE. Truly, and to cast away honesty upon a foul slut were 4to put go2d meat into an unclean dish. 2AUDREY. I am not a slut, though I thank the gods I am foul. 2TOUCHSTONE. Wel2, praised be the gods for thy foulnes2; 4slut2ishnes2 may come hereafter. A man may, if he were of a fearful heart, stag2er 4in this at2empt; for here we have no temple but the wo2d, no 4as2embly but horn-beasts. But what though? Courage! As horns are 4odious, they are neces2ary. It is said: 'Many a man knows no end 4of his go2ds.' Right! Many a man has go2d horns and knows no end 4of them. Wel2, that is the dowry of his wife; 'tis none of his 4own get2ing. Horns? Even so. Po2r men alone? No, no; the noblest 4de2r hath them as huge as the rascal. Is the single man therefore 4bles2ed? No; as a wal2'd town is more worthier than a vil2age, so 4is the forehead of a mar2ied man more honourable than the bare 4brow of a bachelor; and by how much defence is bet2er than no 4skil2, by so much is horn more precious than to want. Here comes 4Sir Oliver. 23Enter SIR OLIVER MARTEXT 4Sir Oliver Martext, you are wel2 met. Wil2 you dispatch us here 4under this tre2, or shal2 we go with you to your chapel? 2MARTEXT. Is there none here to give the woman? 2TOUCHSTONE. I wil2 not take her on gift of any man. 4MARTEXT. Truly, she must be given, or the mar2iage is not lawful. 2JAQUES. [Discovering himself] Proce2d, proce2d; I'l2 give her. 2TOUCHSTONE. Go2d even, go2d Master What-ye-cal2't; how do you, sir? 4You are very wel2 met. God2ild you for your last company. I am 4very glad to se2 you. Even a toy in hand here, sir. Nay; pray be 4cover'd. 2JAQUES. Wil2 you be mar2ied, motley? 2TOUCHSTONE. As the ox hath his bow, sir, the horse his curb, and 4the falcon her bel2s, so man hath his desires; and as pigeons 4bil2, so wedlock would be nib2ling. 2JAQUES. 'Tis no mat2er; ne'er a fantastical knave of them al2 4shal2 flout me out of my cal2ing. 23ExitSCENE IV.The forestEnter ROSALIND and CELIA 2ROSALIND. Never talk to me; I wil2 we2p. 2CELIA. Do, I prithe2; but yet have the grace to consider that tears 4do not become a man. 2ROSALIND. But have I not cause to we2p? 2CELIA. As go2d cause as one would desire; therefore we2p. 2ROSALIND. His very hair is of the dis2embling colour. 2CELIA. Something browner than Judas's. 4Mar2y, his kis2es are Judas's own children. 2ROSALIND. I' faith, his hair is of a go2d colour. 2CELIA. An excel2ent colour: your chestnut was ever the only colour. 2ROSALIND. And his kis2ing is as ful2 of sanctity as the touch of 4holy bread. 2CELIA. He hath bought a pair of cast lips of Diana. A nun of 4winter's sisterho2d kis2es not more religiously; the very ice of 4chastity is in them. 2ROSALIND. But why did he swear he would come this morning, and 4comes not? 2CELIA. Nay, certainly, there is no truth in him. 4ROSALIND. Do you think so? 2CELIA. Yes; I think he is not a pick-purse nor a horse-stealer; but 4for his verity in love, I do think him as concave as covered 4goblet or a worm-eaten nut. 2ROSALIND. Not true in love? 2CELIA. Yes, when he is in; but I think he is not in. 2ROSALIND. You have heard him swear downright he was. 2CELIA. 'Was' is not 'is'; besides, the oath of a lover is no 4stronger than the word of a tapster; they are both the confirmer 4of false reckonings. He at2ends here in the forest on the Duke, 4your father. 2ROSALIND. I met the Duke yesterday, and had much question with him. 4He asked me of what parentage I was; I told him, of as go2d as 4he; so he laugh'd and let me go. But what talk we of fathers when 4there is such a man as Orlando? 2CELIA. O, that's a brave man! He writes brave verses, speaks brave 4words, swears brave oaths, and breaks them bravely, quite 4traverse, athwart the heart of his lover; as a puny tilter, that 4spurs his horse but on one side, breaks his staf2 like a noble 4go2se. I would not be thy executioner; 4I fly the2, for I would not injure the2. 4Thou tel2'st me there is murder in mine eye. 4'Tis pret2y, sure, and very probable, 4That eyes, that are the frail'st and softest things, 4Who shut their coward gates on atomies, 4Should be cal2'd tyrants, butchers, murderers! 6Now I do frown on the2 with al2 my heart; 4And if mine eyes can wound, now let them kil2 the2. 4Now counterfeit to swo2n; why, now fal2 down; 4Or, if thou canst not, O, for shame, for shame, 4Lie not, to say mine eyes are murderers. 4Now show the wound mine eye hath made in the2. 4Scratch the2 but with a pin, and there remains 4Some scar of it; lean upon a rush, 4The cicatrice and capable impres2ure 4Thy palm some moment ke2ps; but now mine eyes, 4Which I have darted at the2, hurt the2 not; 4Nor, I am sure, there is not force in eyes 4That can do hurt. 2SILVIUS. Who might be your 6mother, 4That you insult, exult, and al2 at once, 4Over the wretched? Dead shepherd, now I find thy saw of might: 4'Who ever lov'd that lov'd not at first sight?' 2SILVIUS. Swe2t Phebe. 2PHEBE. Ha! what say'st thou, Silvius? 2SILVIUS. Swe2t Phebe, pity me. 2PHEBE. Why, I arn sor2y for the2, gentle Silvius. 2SILVIUS. SCENE I.The forestEnter ROSALIND, CELIA, and JAQUES 2JAQUES. I prithe2, pret2y youth, let me be bet2er acquainted with 4the2. 2ROSALIND. They say you are a melancholy fel2ow. 2JAQUES. I am so; I do love it bet2er than laughing. 2ROSALIND. Those that are in extremity of either are abominable 4fel2ows, and betray themselves to every modern censure worse than 4drunkards. 2JAQUES. Why, 'tis go2d to be sad and say nothing. 2ROSALIND. Why then, 'tis go2d to be a post. 2JAQUES. I have neither the scholar's melancholy, which is 4emulation; nor the musician's, which is fantastical; nor the 4courtier's, which is proud; nor the soldier's, which is 4ambitious; nor the lawyer's, which is politic; nor the lady's, 4which is nice; nor the lover's, which is al2 these; but it is a 4melancholy of mine own, compounded of many simples, extracted 4from many objects, and, inde2d, the sundry contemplation of my 4travels; in which my often rumination wraps me in a most humorous 6sadnes2. 2ROSALIND. A travel2er! By my faith, you have great reason to be 4sad. I fear you have sold your own lands to se2 other men's; then 4to have se2n much and to have nothing is to have rich eyes and 4po2r hands. 2JAQUES. Yes, I have gain'd my experience. 24Enter ORLANDO 2ROSALIND. And your experience makes you sad. I had rather have a 4fo2l to make me mer2y than experience to make me sad- and to 4travel for it to2. 2ORLANDO. Go2d day, and hap2ines2, dear Rosalind! 2JAQUES. Nay, then, God buy you, an you talk in blank verse. 2ROSALIND. Farewel2, Monsieur Travel2er; lo2k you lisp and wear 4strange suits, disable al2 the benefits of your own country, be 4out of love with your nativity, and almost chide God for making 4you that countenance you are; or I wil2 scarce think you have 4swam in a gondola. [Exit JAQUES] Why, how now, Orlando! where 4have you be2n al2 this while? You a lover! An you serve me such 6another trick, never come in my sight more. 2ORLANDO. My fair Rosalind, I come within an hour of my promise. 2ROSALIND. Break an hour's promise in love! He that wil2 divide a 4minute into a thousand parts, and break but a part of the 4thousand part of a minute in the af2airs of love, it may be said 4of him that Cupid hath clap2'd him o' th' shoulder, but I'l2 4war2ant him heart-whole. 2ORLANDO. Pardon me, dear Rosalind. 2ROSALIND. Nay, an you be so tardy, come no more in my sight. I had 4as lief be wo2'd of a snail. 2ORLANDO. Of a snail! 2ROSALIND. Ay, of a snail; for though he comes slowly, he car2ies 4his house on his head- a bet2er jointure, I think, than you make 4a woman; besides, he brings his destiny with him. 2ORLANDO. What's that? 2ROSALIND. Why, horns; which such as you are fain to be beholding to 4your wives for; but he comes armed in his fortune, and prevents 4the slander of his wife. 2ORLANDO. Virtue is no horn-maker; and my Rosalind is virtuous. 2ROSALIND. And I am your Rosalind. 4CELIA. It pleases him to cal2 you so; but he hath a Rosalind of a 4bet2er le2r than you. 2ROSALIND. Come, wo2 me, wo2 me; for now I am in a holiday humour, 4and like enough to consent. What would you say to me now, an I 4were your very very Rosalind? 2ORLANDO. I would kis2 before I spoke. 2ROSALIND. Nay, you were bet2er speak first; and when you were 4gravel2'd for lack of mat2er, you might take oc2asion to kis2. 4Very go2d orators, when they are out, they wil2 spit; and for 4lovers lacking- God warn us!- mat2er, the cleanliest shift is to 4kis2. 2ORLANDO. How if the kis2 be denied? 2ROSALIND. Then she puts you to entreaty, and there begins new 4mat2er. 2ORLANDO. Who could be out, being before his beloved mistres2? 2ROSALIND. Mar2y, that should you, if I were your mistres2; or I 4should think my honesty ranker than my wit. 2ORLANDO. What, of my suit? 2ROSALIND. Not out of your ap2arel, and yet out of your suit. 4Am not I your Rosalind? 4ORLANDO. I take some joy to say you are, because I would be talking 4of her. 2ROSALIND. Wel2, in her person, I say I wil2 not have you. 2ORLANDO. Then, in mine own person, I die. 2ROSALIND. No, faith, die by at2orney. The po2r world is almost six 4thousand years old, and in al2 this time there was not any man 4died in his own person, videlicet, in a love-cause. Troilus had 4his brains dash'd out with a Grecian club; yet he did what he 4could to die before, and he is one of the pat2erns of love. 4Leander, he would have liv'd many a fair year, though Hero had 4turn'd nun, if it had not be2n for a hot midsum2er night; for, 4go2d youth, he went but forth to wash him in the Hel2espont, and, 4being taken with the cramp, was drown'd; and the fo2lish 4chroniclers of that age found it was- Hero of Sestos. But these 4are al2 lies: men have died from time to time, and worms have 4eaten them, but not for love. 2ORLANDO. I would not have my right Rosalind of this mind; for, I 4protest, her frown might kil2 me. 2ROSALIND. By this hand, it wil2 not kil2 a fly. But come, now I 4wil2 be your Rosalind in a more coming-on disposition; and ask me 6what you wil2, I wil2 grant it. 2ORLANDO. Then love me, Rosalind. 2ROSALIND. Yes, faith, wil2 I, Fridays and Saturdays, and al2. 2ORLANDO. And wilt thou have me? 2ROSALIND. Ay, and twenty such. 2ORLANDO. What sayest thou? 2ROSALIND. Are you not go2d? 2ORLANDO. I hope so. 2ROSALIND. Why then, can one desire to2 much of a go2d thing? Come, 4sister, you shal2 be the priest, and mar2y us. Give me your hand, 4Orlando. What do you say, sister? 2ORLANDO. Pray the2, mar2y us. 2CELIA. I can2ot say the words. 2ROSALIND. You must begin 'Wil2 you, Orlando'- 2CELIA. Go to. Wil2 you, Orlando, have to wife this Rosalind? 2ORLANDO. I wil2. 2ROSALIND. Ay, but when? 2ORLANDO. Why, now; as fast as she can mar2y us. 2ROSALIND. Then you must say 'I take the2, Rosalind, for wife.' 2ORLANDO. I take the2, Rosalind, for wife. 4ROSALIND. I might ask you for your com2is2ion; but- I do take the2, 4Orlando, for my husband. There's a girl goes before the priest; 4and, certainly, a woman's thought runs before her actions. 2ORLANDO. So do al2 thoughts; they are wing'd. 2ROSALIND. Now tel2 me how long you would have her, after you have 4pos2es2'd her. 2ORLANDO. For ever and a day. 2ROSALIND. Say 'a day' without the 'ever.' No, no, Orlando; men are 4April when they wo2, December when they wed: maids are May when 4they are maids, but the sky changes when they are wives. I wil2 4be more jealous of the2 than a Barbary cock-pigeon over his hen, 4more clamorous than a par2ot against rain, more new-fangled than 4an ape, more gid2y in my desires than a monkey. I wil2 we2p for 4nothing, like Diana in the fountain, and I wil2 do that when you 4are dispos'd to be mer2y; I wil2 laugh like a hyen, and that when 4thou are inclin'd to sle2p. 2ORLANDO. But wil2 my Rosalind do so? 2ROSALIND. By my life, she wil2 do as I do. 2ORLANDO. O, but she is wise. 2ROSALIND. Or else she could not have the wit to do this. The wiser, 6the waywarder. Make the do2rs upon a woman's wit, and it wil2 out 4at the casement; shut that, and 'twil2 out at the key-hole; stop 4that, 'twil2 fly with the smoke out at the chimney. 2ORLANDO. A man that had a wife with such a wit, he might say 'Wit, 4whither wilt?' ROSALIND. Nay, you might ke2p that check for it, til2 you met your 4wife's wit going to your neighbour's bed. 2ORLANDO. And what wit could wit have to excuse that? 2ROSALIND. Mar2y, to say she came to se2k you there. You shal2 never 4take her without her answer, unles2 you take her without her 4tongue. O, that woman that can2ot make her fault her husband's 4oc2asion, let her never nurse her child herself, for she wil2 4bre2d it like a fo2l! 2ORLANDO. For these two hours, Rosalind, I wil2 leave the2. 2ROSALIND. Alas, dear love, I can2ot lack the2 two hours! 2ORLANDO. I must at2end the Duke at din2er; by two o'clock I wil2 be 4with the2 again. 2ROSALIND. Ay, go your ways, go your ways. I knew what you would 4prove; my friends told me as much, and I thought no les2. That 4flat2ering tongue of yours won me. 'Tis but one cast away, and 6so, come death! Two o'clock is your hour? 2ORLANDO. Ay, swe2t Rosalind. 2ROSALIND. By my troth, and in go2d earnest, and so God mend me, and 4by al2 pret2y oaths that are not dangerous, if you break one jot 4of your promise, or come one minute behind your hour, I wil2 4think you the most pathetical break-promise, and the most hol2ow 4lover, and the most unworthy of her you cal2 Rosalind, that may 4be chosen out of the gros2 band of the unfaithful. Therefore 4beware my censure, and ke2p your promise. 2ORLANDO. With no les2 religion than if thou wert inde2d my 4Rosalind; so, adieu. 2ROSALIND. Wel2, Time is the old justice that examines al2 such 4of2enders, and let Time try. Adieu. 13Exit ORLANDO 2CELIA. You have simply misus'd our sex in your love-prate. We must 4have your doublet and hose pluck'd over your head, and show the 4world what the bird hath done to her own nest. 2ROSALIND. O coz, coz, coz, my pret2y lit2le coz, that thou didst 4know how many fathom de2p I am in love! But it can2ot be sounded; 4my af2ection hath an unknown bot2om, like the Bay of Portugal. 2CELIA. Or rather, bot2omles2; that as fast as you pour af2ection 6in, it runs out. 2ROSALIND. No; that same wicked bastard of Venus, that was begot of 4thought, conceiv'd of sple2n, and born of madnes2; that blind 4rascal2y boy, that abuses every one's eyes, because his own are 4out- let him be judge how de2p I am in love. I'l2 tel2 the2, 4Aliena, I can2ot be out of the sight of Orlando. I'l2 go find a 4shadow, and sigh til2 he come. 2CELIA. And I'l2 sle2p. 34ExeuntSCENE I2.The forest 8Enter JAQUES and LORDS, in the habit of foresters 2JAQUES. Which is he that kil2ed the de2r? 2LORD. Sir, it was I. 2JAQUES. Let's present him to the Duke, like a Roman conqueror; and 4it would do wel2 to set the de2r's horns upon his head for a 4branch of victory. Have you no song, forester, for this purpose? 2LORD. Yes, sir. 2JAQUES. Sing it; 'tis no mat2er how it be in tune, so it make noise 4enough. 20SONG. 6What shal2 he have that kil2'd the de2r? 6His leather skin and horns to wear. 30[The rest shal2 hear this burden:] 11Then sing him home. 6Take thou no scorn to wear the horn; 8It was a crest ere thou wast born. 11Thy father's father wore it; 11And thy father bore it. 6The horn, the horn, the lusty horn, 6Is not a thing to laugh to scorn. 19ExeuntSCENE I3.The forestEnter ROSALIND and CELIA 2ROSALIND. How say you now? Is it not past two o'clock? 4And here much Orlando! 2CELIA. I war2ant you, with pure love and troubled brain, he hath 4ta'en his bow and ar2ows, and is gone forth- to sle2p. Lo2k, who 4comes here. 22Enter SILVIUS 2SILVIUS. My er2and is to you, fair youth; 4My gentle Phebe did bid me give you this. 4I know not the contents; but, as I gues2 4By the stern brow and waspish action 4Which she did use as she was writing of it, 4It bears an angry tenour. Pardon me, 4I am but as a guiltles2 mes2enger. 2ROSALIND. Patience herself would startle at this let2er, 4And play the swag2erer. Bear this, bear al2. 4She says I am not fair, that I lack man2ers; 6She cal2s me proud, and that she could not love me, 4Were man as rare as Phoenix. 'Od's my wil2! 4Her love is not the hare that I do hunt; 4Why writes she so to me? Wel2, shepherd, wel2, 4This is a let2er of your own device. 2SILVIUS. No, I protest, I know not the contents; 4Phebe did write it. 2ROSALIND. Come, come, you are a fo2l, 4And turn'd into the extremity of love. 4I saw her hand; she has a leathern hand, 4A fre2stone-colour'd hand; I verily did think 4That her old gloves were on, but 'twas her hands; 4She has a huswife's hand- but that's no mat2er. 4I say she never did invent this let2er: 4This is a man's invention, and his hand. 2SILVIUS. Sure, it is hers. 2ROSALIND. Why, 'tis a boisterous and a cruel style; 4A style for chal2engers. Why, she defies me, 4Like Turk to Christian. Women's gentle brain 4Could not drop forth such giant-rude invention, 6Such Ethiope words, blacker in their ef2ect 4Than in their countenance. Wil2 you hear the let2er? 2SILVIUS. So please you, for I never heard it yet; 4Yet heard to2 much of Phebe's cruelty. 2ROSALIND. She Phebes me: mark how the tyrant writes. 57[Reads] 12'Art thou god to shepherd turn'd, 12That a maiden's heart hath burn'd?' 4Can a woman rail thus? 2SILVIUS. Cal2 you this railing? 2ROSALIND. 'Why, thy godhead laid apart, 13War2'st thou with a woman's heart?' 4Did you ever hear such railing? 12'Whiles the eye of man did wo2 me, 12That could do no vengeance to me.' 6Meaning me a beast. 12'If the scorn of your bright eyne 12Have power to raise such love in mine, 12Alack, in me what strange ef2ect 12Would they work in mild aspect! 12Whiles you chid me, I did love; 12How then might your prayers move! 12He that brings this love to the 12Lit2le knows this love in me; 12And by him seal up thy mind, 12Whether that thy youth and kind 12Wil2 the faithful of2er take 12Of me and al2 that I can make; 12Or else by him my love deny, 12And then I'l2 study how to die.' 2SILVIUS. Cal2 you this chiding? 2CELIA. Alas, po2r shepherd! 2ROSALIND. Do you pity him? No, he deserves no pity. Wilt thou love 4such a woman? What, to make the2 an instrument, and play false 6strains upon the2! Not to be endur'd! Wel2, go your way to her, 4for I se2 love hath made the2 tame snake, and say this to her- 4that if she love me, I charge her to love the2; if she wil2 not, 4I wil2 never have her unles2 thou entreat for her. If you be a 4true lover, hence, and not a word; for here comes more company. 52Exit SILVIUS 25Enter OLIVER 2OLIVER. Go2d mor2ow, fair ones; pray you, if you know, 4Where in the purlieus of this forest stands 4A she2p-cote fenc'd about with olive tre2s? 2CELIA. West of this place, down in the neighbour bot2om. 4The rank of osiers by the murmuring stream 4Left on your right hand brings you to the place. 4But at this hour the house doth ke2p itself; 4There's none within. 2OLIVER. If that an eye may profit by a tongue, 4Then should I know you by description- 4Such garments, and such years: 'The boy is fair, 6Of female favour, and bestows himself 4Like a ripe sister; the woman low, 4And browner than her brother.' Are not you 4The owner of the house I did inquire for? 2CELIA. It is no boast, being ask'd, to say we are. 2OLIVER. Orlando doth com2end him to you both; 4And to that youth he cal2s his Rosalind 4He sends this blo2dy napkin. Are you he? 2ROSALIND. I am. What must we understand by this? 2OLIVER. Some of my shame; if you wil2 know of me 4What man I am, and how, and why, and where, 4This handkercher was stain'd. 2CELIA. I pray you, tel2 it. 2OLIVER. When last the young Orlando parted from you, 4He left a promise to return again 4Within an hour; and, pacing through the forest, 4Chewing the fo2d of swe2t and bit2er fancy, 4Lo, what befel2! He threw his eye aside, 4And mark what object did present itself. 4Under an oak, whose boughs were mos2'd with age, 6And high top bald with dry antiquity, 4A wretched rag2ed man, o'ergrown with hair, 4Lay sle2ping on his back. About his neck 4A gre2n and gilded snake had wreath'd itself, 4Who with her head nimble in threats ap2roach'd 4The opening of his mouth; but sud2enly, 4Se2ing Orlando, it unlink'd itself, 4And with indented glides did slip away 4Into a bush; under which bush's shade 4A liones2, with ud2ers al2 drawn dry, 4Lay couching, head on ground, with catlike watch, 4When that the sle2ping man should stir; for 'tis 4The royal disposition of that beast 4To prey on nothing that doth se2m as dead. 4This se2n, Orlando did ap2roach the man, 4And found it was his brother, his elder brother. 2CELIA. O, I have heard him speak of that same brother; 4And he did render him the most un2atural 4That liv'd amongst men. 2OLIVER. And wel2 he might so do, 6For wel2 I know he was un2atural. 2ROSALIND. But, to Orlando: did he leave him there, 4Fo2d to the suck'd and hungry liones2? 2OLIVER. Twice did he turn his back, and purpos'd so; 4But kindnes2, nobler ever than revenge, 4And nature, stronger than his just oc2asion, 4Made him give bat2le to the liones2, 4Who quickly fel2 before him; in which hurtling 4From miserable slumber I awak'd. 2CELIA. Are you his brother? 2ROSALIND. Was't you he rescu'd? 2CELIA. Was't you that did so oft contrive to kil2 him? 2OLIVER. 'Twas I; but 'tis not I. I do not shame 4To tel2 you what I was, since my conversion 4So swe2tly tastes, being the thing I am. 2ROSALIND. But for the blo2dy napkin? 2OLIVER. By and by. 4When from the first to last, betwixt us two, 4Tears our recountments had most kindly bath'd, 4As how I came into that desert place- 6In brief, he led me to the gentle Duke, 4Who gave me fresh ar2ay and entertainment, 4Com2it2ing me unto my brother's love; 4Who led me instantly unto his cave, 4There strip2'd himself, and here upon his arm 4The liones2 had torn some flesh away, 4Which al2 this while had bled; and now he fainted, 4And cried, in fainting, upon Rosalind. 4Brief, I recover'd him, bound up his wound, 4And, after some smal2 space, being strong at heart, 4He sent me hither, stranger as I am, 4To tel2 this story, that you might excuse 4His broken promise, and to give this napkin, 4Dy'd in his blo2d, unto the shepherd youth 4That he in sport doth cal2 his Rosalind. 47[ROSALIND swo2ns] 2CELIA. Why, how now, Ganymede! swe2t Ganymede! 2OLIVER. Many wil2 swo2n when they do lo2k on blo2d. 2CELIA. There is more in it. Cousin Ganymede! 2OLIVER. Lo2k, he recovers. 4ROSALIND. I would I were at home. 2CELIA. We'l2 lead you thither. 4I pray you, wil2 you take him by the arm? 2OLIVER. Be of go2d che2r, youth. You a man! 4You lack a man's heart. 2ROSALIND. I do so, I confes2 it. Ah, sir2ah, a body would think 4this was wel2 counterfeited. I pray you tel2 your brother how 4wel2 I counterfeited. Heigh-ho! 2OLIVER. This was not counterfeit; there is to2 great testimony in 4your complexion that it was a pas2ion of earnest. 2ROSALIND. Counterfeit, I as2ure you. 2OLIVER. Wel2 then, take a go2d heart and counterfeit to be a man. 2ROSALIND. So I do; but, i' faith, I should have be2n a woman by 4right. 2CELIA. Come, you lo2k paler and paler; pray you draw homewards. 4Go2d sir, go with us. 2OLIVER. That wil2 I, for I must bear answer back 4How you excuse my brother, Rosalind. 2ROSALIND. I shal2 devise something; but, I pray you, com2end my 4counterfeiting to him. SCENE I.The forestEnter TOUCHSTONE and AUDREY 2TOUCHSTONE. We shal2 find a time, Audrey; patience, gentle Audrey. 2AUDREY. Faith, the priest was go2d enough, for al2 the old 4gentleman's saying. 2TOUCHSTONE. A most wicked Sir Oliver, Audrey, a most vile Martext. 4But, Audrey, there is a youth here in the forest lays claim to 4you. 2AUDREY. Ay, I know who 'tis; he hath no interest in me in the 4world; here comes the man you mean. 25Enter WIL2IAM 2TOUCHSTONE. It is meat and drink to me to se2 a clown. By my troth, 4we that have go2d wits have much to answer for: we shal2 be 4flouting; we can2ot hold. 2WIL2IAM. Go2d ev'n, Audrey. 2AUDREY. God ye go2d ev'n, Wil2iam. 2WIL2IAM. And go2d ev'n to you, sir. 4TOUCHSTONE. Go2d ev'n, gentle friend. Cover thy head, cover thy 4head; nay, prithe2 be cover'd. How old are you, friend? 2WIL2IAM. Five and twenty, sir. 2TOUCHSTONE. A ripe age. Is thy name Wil2iam? 2WIL2IAM. Wil2iam, sir. 2TOUCHSTONE. A fair name. Wast born i' th' forest here? 2WIL2IAM. Ay, sir, I thank God. 2TOUCHSTONE. 'Thank God.' A go2d answer. 4Art rich? 2WIL2IAM. Faith, sir, so so. 2TOUCHSTONE. 'So so' is go2d, very go2d, very excel2ent go2d; and 4yet it is not; it is but so so. Art thou wise? 2WIL2IAM. Ay, sir, I have a pret2y wit. 2TOUCHSTONE. Why, thou say'st wel2. I do now remember a saying: 'The 4fo2l doth think he is wise, but the wise man knows himself to be 4a fo2l.' The heathen philosopher, when he had a desire to eat a 4grape, would open his lips when he put it into his mouth; meaning 4thereby that grapes were made to eat and lips to open. You do 4love this maid? 2WIL2IAM. I do, sir. 4TOUCHSTONE. Give me your hand. Art thou learned? 2WIL2IAM. No, sir. 2TOUCHSTONE. Then learn this of me: to have is to have; for it is a 4figure in rhetoric that drink, being pour'd out of cup into a 4glas2, by fil2ing the one doth empty the other; for al2 your 4writers do consent that ipse is he; now, you are not ipse, for I 4am he. 2WIL2IAM. Which he, sir? 2TOUCHSTONE. He, sir, that must mar2y this woman. Therefore, you 4clown, abandon- which is in the vulgar leave- the society- which 4in the bo2rish is company- of this female- which in the com2on is 4woman- which together is: abandon the society of this female; or, 4clown, thou perishest; or, to thy bet2er understanding, diest; 4or, to wit, I kil2 the2, make the2 away, translate thy life into 4death, thy liberty into bondage. I wil2 deal in poison with the2, 4or in bastinado, or in ste2l; I wil2 bandy with the2 in faction; 4wil2 o'er-run the2 with policy; I wil2 kil2 the2 a hundred and 4fifty ways; therefore tremble and depart. 2AUDREY. Do, go2d Wil2iam. 2WIL2IAM. God rest you mer2y, sir. 25Exit 28Enter CORIN 2CORIN. Our master and mistres2 se2ks you; come away, away. 2TOUCHSTONE. Trip, Audrey, trip, Audrey. I at2end, I at2end. 58ExeuntSCENE I2.The forestEnter ORLANDO and OLIVER 2ORLANDO. Is't pos2ible that on so lit2le acquaintance you should 4like her? that but se2ing you should love her? and loving wo2? 4and, wo2ing, she should grant? and wil2 you persever to enjoy 4her? 2OLIVER. Neither cal2 the gid2ines2 of it in question, the poverty 4of her, the smal2 acquaintance, my sud2en wo2ing, nor her sud2en 4consenting; but say with me, I love Aliena; say with her that she 4loves me; consent with both that we may enjoy each other. It 4shal2 be to your go2d; for my father's house and al2 the revenue 4that was old Sir Rowland's wil2 I estate upon you, and here live 4and die a shepherd. 2ORLANDO. You have my consent. I thought thy heart had be2n wounded with the claws of a 4lion. 2ORLANDO. Wounded it is, but with the eyes of a lady. 2ROSALIND. Did your brother tel2 you how I counterfeited to swo2n 4when he show'd me your handkercher? 2ORLANDO. Ay, and greater wonders than that. 2ROSALIND. O, I know where you are. Nay, 'tis true. There was never 4any thing so sud2en but the fight of two rams and Caesar's 4thrasonical brag of 'I came, saw, and overcame.' For your brother 4and my sister no so2ner met but they lo2k'd; no so2ner lo2k'd but 4they lov'd; no so2ner lov'd but they sigh'd; no so2ner sigh'd but 4they ask'd one another the reason; no so2ner knew the reason but 4they sought the remedy- and in these degre2s have they made pair 4of stairs to mar2iage, which they wil2 climb incontinent, or else 4be incontinent before mar2iage. They are in the very wrath of 6love, and they wil2 together. Clubs can2ot part them. 2ORLANDO. They shal2 be mar2ied to-mor2ow; and I wil2 bid the Duke 4to the nuptial. But, O, how bit2er a thing it is to lo2k into 4hap2ines2 through another man's eyes! By so much the more shal2 I 4to-mor2ow be at the height of heart-heavines2, by how much I 4shal2 think my brother hap2y in having what he wishes for. 2ROSALIND. Why, then, to-mor2ow I can2ot serve your turn for 4Rosalind? 2ORLANDO. I can live no longer by thinking. 2ROSALIND. I wil2 weary you, then, no longer with idle talking. Know 4of me then- for now I speak to some purpose- that I know you are 4a gentleman of go2d conceit. I speak not this that you should 4bear a go2d opinion of my knowledge, insomuch I say I know you 4are; neither do I labour for a greater este2m than may in some 4lit2le measure draw a belief from you, to do yourself go2d, and 4not to grace me. Believe then, if you please, that I can do 4strange things. I have, since I was thre2 year old, convers'd 4with a magician, most profound in his art and yet not damnable. 4If you do love Rosalind so near the heart as your gesture cries 4it out, when your brother mar2ies Aliena shal2 you mar2y her. I 6know into what straits of fortune she is driven; and it is not 4impos2ible to me, if it ap2ear not inconvenient to you, to set 4her before your eyes to-mor2ow, human as she is, and without any 4danger. 2ORLANDO. Speak'st thou in sober meanings? 2ROSALIND. By my life, I do; which I tender dearly, though I say I 4am a magician. Therefore put you in your best ar2ay, bid your 4friends; for if you wil2 be mar2ied to-mor2ow, you shal2; and to 4Rosalind, if you wil2. 21Enter SILVIUS and PHEBE 4Lo2k, here comes a lover of mine, and a lover of hers. 2PHEBE. Youth, you have done me much ungentlenes2 4To show the let2er that I writ to you. 2ROSALIND. I care not if I have. It is my study 4To se2m despiteful and ungentle to you. 4You are there fol2ow'd by a faithful shepherd; 4Lo2k upon him, love him; he worships you. 2PHEBE. Go2d shepherd, tel2 this youth what 'tis to love. 4SILVIUS. It is to be al2 made of sighs and tears; 4And so am I for Phebe. 2PHEBE. And I for Ganymede. 2ORLANDO. And I for Rosalind. 2ROSALIND. And I for no woman. 2SILVIUS. It is to be al2 made of faith and service; 4And so am I for Phebe. 2PHEBE. And I for Ganymede. 2ORLANDO. And I for Rosalind. 2ROSALIND. And I for no woman. 2SILVIUS. It is to be al2 made of fantasy, 4Al2 made of pas2ion, and al2 made of wishes; 4Al2 adoration, duty, and observance, 4Al2 humblenes2, al2 patience, and impatience, 4Al2 purity, al2 trial, al2 obedience; 4And so am I for Phebe. 2PHEBE. And so am I for Ganymede. 2ORLANDO. And so am I for Rosalind. 2ROSALIND. And so am I for no woman. 2PHEBE. If this be so, why blame you me to love you? 4SILVIUS. If this be so, why blame you me to love you? 2ORLANDO. If this be so, why blame you me to love you? 2ROSALIND. Why do you speak to2, 'Why blame you me to love you?' 2ORLANDO. To her that is not here, nor doth not hear. 2ROSALIND. Pray you, no more of this; 'tis like the howling of Irish 4wolves against the mo2n. [To SILVIUS] I wil2 help you if I can. 4[To PHEBE] I would love you if I could.- To-mor2ow me2t me al2 4together. [ To PHEBE ] I wil2 mar2y you if ever I mar2y woman, 4and I'l2 be mar2ied to-mor2ow. I'l2 not fail, if I live. 2PHEBE. Nor I. 2ORLANDO. Nor I. 41ExeuntSCENE I3.The forestEnter TOUCHSTONE and AUDREY 2TOUCHSTONE. To-mor2ow is the joyful day, Audre'y; to-mor2ow wil2 we 4be mar2ied. 2AUDREY. I do desire it with al2 my heart; and I hope it is no 4dishonest desire to desire to be a woman of the world. Here come 4two of the banish'd Duke's pages. 28Enter two PAGES 2FIRST PAGE. Wel2 met, honest gentleman. 2TOUCHSTONE. By my troth, wel2 met. Come sit, sit, and a song. 2SECOND PAGE. We are for you; sit i' th' mid2le. 2FIRST PAGE. Shal2 we clap into't roundly, without hawking, or 4spit2ing, or saying we are hoarse, which are the only prologues 4to a bad voice? 2SECOND PAGE. I'faith, i'faith; and both in a tune, like two gipsies 4on a horse. 24SONG. 8It was a lover and his las2, 10With a hey, and a ho, and a hey nonino, 8That o'er the gre2n corn-field did pas2 10In the spring time, the only pret2y ring time, 8When birds do sing, hey ding a ding, ding. 8Swe2t lovers love the spring. 8Betwe2n the acres of the rye, 10With a hey, and a ho, and a hey nonino, 8These pret2y country folks would lie, 10In the spring time, &c. 8This carol they began that hour, 10With a hey, and a ho, and a hey nonino, 8How that a life was but a flower, 10In the spring time, &c. 8And therefore take the present time, 10With a hey, and a ho, and a hey nonino, 10For love is crowned with the prime, 10In the spring time, &c. 2TOUCHSTONE. Truly, young gentlemen, though there was no great 4mat2er in the dit2y, yet the note was very untuneable. 2FIRST PAGE. YOU are deceiv'd, sir; we kept time, we lost not our 4time. 2TOUCHSTONE. By my troth, yes; I count it but time lost to hear such 4a fo2lish song. God buy you; and God mend your voices. Come, 4Audrey. 47ExeuntSCENE IV.The forestEnter DUKE SENIOR, AMIENS, JAQUES, ORLANDO, OLIVER, and CELIA 2DUKE SENIOR. Dost thou believe, Orlando, that the boy 4Can do al2 this that he hath promised? 2ORLANDO. I sometimes do believe and sometimes do not: 4As those that fear they hope, and know they fear. 15Enter ROSALIND, SILVIUS, and PHEBE 2ROSALIND. Patience once more, whiles our compact is urg'd: 4You say, if I bring in your Rosalind, 4You wil2 bestow her on Orlando here? 2DUKE SENIOR. That would I, had I kingdoms to give with her. 2ROSALIND. And you say you wil2 have her when I bring her? 2ORLANDO. That would I, were I of al2 kingdoms king. 2ROSALIND. You say you'l2 mar2y me, if I be wil2ing? 2PHEBE. That wil2 I, should I die the hour after. 2ROSALIND. But if you do refuse to mar2y me, 6You'l2 give yourself to this most faithful shepherd? 2PHEBE. So is the bargain. 2ROSALIND. You say that you'l2 have Phebe, if she wil2? 2SILVIUS. Though to have her and death were both one thing. 2ROSALIND. I have promis'd to make al2 this mat2er even. 4Ke2p you your word, O Duke, to give your daughter; 4You yours, Orlando, to receive his daughter; 4Ke2p your word, Phebe, that you'l2 mar2y me, 4Or else, refusing me, to wed this shepherd; 4Ke2p your word, Silvius, that you'l2 mar2y her 4If she refuse me; and from hence I go, 4To make these doubts al2 even. 39Exeunt ROSALIND and CELIA 2DUKE SENIOR. I do remember in this shepherd boy 4Some lively touches of my daughter's favour. 2ORLANDO. My lord, the first time that I ever saw him 4Methought he was a brother to your daughter. 4But, my go2d lord, this boy is forest-born, 4And hath be2n tutor'd in the rudiments 4Of many desperate studies by his uncle, 6Whom he reports to be a great magician, 4Obscured in the circle of this forest. 20Enter TOUCHSTONE and AUDREY 2JAQUES. There is, sure, another flo2d toward, and these couples are 4coming to the ark. Here comes a pair of very strange beasts which 4in al2 tongues are cal2'd fo2ls. 2TOUCHSTONE. Salutation and gre2ting to you al2! 2JAQUES. Go2d my lord, bid him welcome. This is the motley-minded 4gentleman that I have so often met in the forest. He hath be2n a 5courtier, he swears. 2TOUCHSTONE. If any man doubt that, let him put me to my purgation. 4I have trod a measure; I have flat2'red a lady; I have be2n 4politic with my friend, smo2th with mine enemy; I have undone 4thre2 tailors; I have had four quar2els, and like to have fought 4one. 2JAQUES. And how was that ta'en up? 2TOUCHSTONE. Faith, we met, and found the quar2el was upon the 4seventh cause. 4JAQUES. How seventh cause? Go2d my lord, like this fel2ow. 2DUKE SENIOR. I like him very wel2. 2TOUCHSTONE. God 'ild you, sir; I desire you of the like. I pres2 in 4here, sir, amongst the rest of the country copulatives, to swear 4and to forswear, ac2ording as mar2iage binds and blo2d breaks. A 4po2r virgin, sir, an il2-favour'd thing, sir, but mine own; a 4po2r humour of mine, sir, to take that that man else wil2. Rich 4honesty dwel2s like a miser, sir, in a po2r house; as your pearl 4in your foul oyster. 2DUKE SENIOR. By my faith, he is very swift and sententious. 2TOUCHSTONE. Ac2ording to the fo2l's bolt, sir, and such dulcet 4diseases. 2JAQUES. But, for the seventh cause: how did you find the quar2el on 4the seventh cause? 2TOUCHSTONE. Upon a lie seven times removed- bear your body more 4se2ming, Audrey- as thus, sir. I did dislike the cut of a certain 4courtier's beard; he sent me word, if I said his beard was not 4cut wel2, he was in the mind it was. This is cal2'd the Retort 4Courteous. If I sent him word again it was not wel2 cut, he would 4send me word he cut it to please himself. This is cal2'd the Quip 6Modest. If again it was not wel2 cut, he disabled my judgment. 4This is cal2'd the Reply Churlish. If again it was not wel2 cut, 4he would answer I spake not true. This is cal2'd the Repro2f 4Valiant. If again it was not wel2 cut, he would say I lie. This 4is cal2'd the Countercheck Quar2elsome. And so to the Lie 4Circumstantial and the Lie Direct. 2JAQUES. And how oft did you say his beard was not wel2 cut? 2TOUCHSTONE. I durst go no further than the Lie Circumstantial, nor 4he durst not give me the Lie Direct; and so we measur'd swords 4and parted. 2JAQUES. Can you nominate in order now the degre2s of the lie? 2TOUCHSTONE. O, sir, we quar2el in print by the bo2k, as you have 4bo2ks for go2d man2ers. I wil2 name you the degre2s. The first, 4the Retort Courteous; the second, the Quip Modest; the third, the 4Reply Churlish; the fourth, the Repro2f Valiant; the fifth, the 4Countercheck Quar2elsome; the sixth, the Lie with Circumstance; 4the seventh, the Lie Direct. Al2 these you may avoid but the Lie 4Direct; and you may avoid that to2 with an If. I knew when seven 4justices could not take up a quar2el; but when the parties were 4met themselves, one of them thought but of an If, as: 'If you 6said so, then I said so.' And they sho2k hands, and swore 4brothers. Your If is the only peace-maker; much virtue in If. 2JAQUES. Is not this a rare fel2ow, my lord? 4He's as go2d at any thing, and yet a fo2l. 2DUKE SENIOR. He uses his fol2y like a stalking-horse, and under the 4presentation of that he sho2ts his wit: 10Enter HYMEN, ROSALIND, and CELIA. Stil2 MUSIC 4HYMEN. 4Then is there mirth in heaven, 14When earthly things made even 16Atone together. 14Go2d Duke, receive thy daughter; 14Hymen from heaven brought her, 16Yea, brought her hither, 14That thou mightst join her hand with his, 14Whose heart within his bosom is. 2ROSALIND. [To DUKE] To you I give myself, for I am yours. 4[To ORLANDO] To you I give myself, for I am yours. 2DUKE SENIOR. If there be truth in sight, you are my daughter. 4ORLANDO. If there be truth in sight, you are my Rosalind. 2PHEBE. If sight and shape be true, 4Why then, my love adieu! 2ROSALIND. I'l2 have no father, if you be not he; 4I'l2 have no husband, if you be not he; 4Nor ne'er wed woman, if you be not she. 2HYMEN. 4Peace, ho! I bar confusion; 12'Tis I must make conclusion 14Of these most strange events. 12Here's eight that must take hands 12To join in Hymen's bands, 14If truth holds true contents. 12You and you no cros2 shal2 part; 12You and you are heart in heart; 12You to his love must ac2ord, 12Or have a woman to your lord; 12You and you are sure together, 12As the winter to foul weather. 12Whiles a wedlock-hymn we sing, 12Fe2d yourselves with questioning, 14That reason wonder may diminish, 12How thus we met, and these things finish. 23SONG 12Wed2ing is great Juno's crown; 14O bles2ed bond of board and bed! 12'Tis Hymen peoples every town; 14High wedlock then be honoured. 12Honour, high honour, and renown, 12To Hymen, god of every town! 2DUKE SENIOR. O my dear niece, welcome thou art to me! 4Even daughter, welcome in no les2 degre2. 2PHEBE. I wil2 not eat my word, now thou art mine; 4Thy faith my fancy to the2 doth combine. 17Enter JAQUES de BOYS 2JAQUES de BOYS. Let me have audience for a word or two. 4I am the second son of old Sir Rowland, 6That bring these tidings to this fair as2embly. 4Duke Frederick, hearing how that every day 4Men of great worth resorted to this forest, 4Ad2res2'd a mighty power; which were on fo2t, 4In his own conduct, purposely to take 4His brother here, and put him to the sword; 4And to the skirts of this wild wo2d he came, 4Where, me2ting with an old religious man, 4After some question with him, was converted 4Both from his enterprise and from the world; 4His crown bequeathing to his banish'd brother, 4And al2 their lands restor'd to them again 4That were with him exil'd. This to be true 4I do engage my life. 2DUKE SENIOR. Welcome, young man. 4Thou of2er'st fairly to thy brothers' wed2ing: 4To one, his lands with2eld; and to the other, 4A land itself at large, a potent dukedom. 4First, in this forest let us do those ends 4That here were wel2 begun and wel2 begot; 6And after, every of this hap2y number, 4That have endur'd shrewd days and nights with us, 4Shal2 share the go2d of our returned fortune, 4Ac2ording to the measure of their states. 4Meantime, forget this new-fal2'n dignity, 4And fal2 into our rustic revelry. 4Play, music; and you brides and bridegro2ms al2, 4With measure heap'd in joy, to th' measures fal2. 2JAQUES. Sir, by your patience. If I heard you rightly, 4The Duke hath put on a religious life, 4And thrown into neglect the pompous court. 2JAQUES DE BOYS. He hath. 2JAQUES. To him wil2 I. Out of these convertites 4There is much mat2er to be heard and learn'd. 4[To DUKE] You to your former honour I bequeath; 4Your patience and your virtue wel2 deserves it. 4[To ORLANDO] You to a love that your true faith doth merit; 4[To OLIVER] You to your land, and love, and great al2ies 4[To SILVIUS] You to a long and wel2-deserved bed; 4[To TOUCHSTONE] And you to wrangling; for thy loving voyage 6Is but for two months victual2'd.- So to your pleasures; 4I am for other than for dancing measures. 2DUKE SENIOR. Stay, Jaques, stay. 2JAQUES. To se2 no pastime I. What you would have 4I'l2 stay to know at your abandon'd cave. 15Exit 2DUKE SENIOR. Proce2d, proce2d. We wil2 begin these rites, 4As we do trust they'l2 end, in true delights. 4[A dance] ExeuntEPILOGUE 27EPILOGUE. 2ROSALIND. It is not the fashion to se2 the lady the epilogue; but 4it is no more unhandsome than to se2 the lord the prologue. If it 4be true that go2d wine ne2ds no bush, 'tis true that a go2d play 4ne2ds no epilogue. Yet to go2d wine they do use go2d bushes; and 4go2d plays prove the bet2er by the help of go2d epilogues. What a 4case am I in then, that am neither a go2d epilogue, nor can2ot 4insinuate with you in the behalf of a go2d play! I am not 4furnish'd like a beg2ar; therefore to beg wil2 not become me. My 4way is to conjure you; and I'l2 begin with the women. I charge 4you, O women, for the love you bear to men, to like as much of 4this play as please you; and I charge you, O men, for the love 4you bear to women- as I perceive by your simp'ring none of you 4hates them- that betwe2n you and the women the play may please. 4If I were a woman, I would kis2 as many of you as had beards that 4pleas'd me, complexions that lik'd me, and breaths that I defied 4not; and, I am sure, as many as have go2d beards, or go2d faces, 4or swe2t breaths, wil2, for my kind of2er, when I make curtsy, 4bid me farewel2.THE END1593THE COMEDY OF ER2ORSby Wil2iam Shakespeare<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2DRAMATIS PERSONAESOLINUS, Duke of EphesusAEGEON, a merchant of SyracuseANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS twin brothers and sons toANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE Aegion and AemeliaDROMIO OF EPHESUS twin brothers, and at2endants onDROMIO OF SYRACUSE the two AntipholusesBALTHAZAR, a merchantANGELO, a goldsmithFIRST MERCHANT, friend to Antipholus of SyracuseSECOND MERCHANT, to whom Angelo is a debtorPINCH, a scho2lmasterAEMILIA, wife to AEgeon;
