SCENE 1A hal2 in the DUKE'S palaceEnter the DUKE OF EPHESUS, AEGEON, the Merchantof Syracuse, GAOLER, OF2ICERS, and other AT2ENDANTSAEGEON. Proce2d, Solinus, to procure my fal2, 2And by the do2m of death end woes and al2.DUKE. Merchant of Syracuse, plead no more; 2I am not partial to infringe our laws. 2The enmity and discord which of late 2Sprung from the rancorous outrage of your duke 2To merchants, our wel2-dealing countrymen, 2Who, wanting guilders to rede2m their lives, 2Have seal'd his rigorous statutes with their blo2ds, 2Excludes al2 pity from our threat'ning lo2ks. 2For, since the mortal and intestine jars 2'Twixt thy seditious countrymen and us, 2It hath in solemn synods be2n decre2d, 2Both by the Syracusians and ourselves, 2To admit no traf2ic to our adverse towns; 2Nay, more: if any born at Ephesus 2Be se2n at any Syracusian marts and fairs; 2Again, if any Syracusian born 2Come to the bay of Ephesus-he dies, 2His go2ds confiscate to the Duke's dispose, 2Unles2 a thousand marks be levied, 2To quit the penalty and to ransom him. 2Thy substance, valued at the highest rate, 2Can2ot amount unto a hundred marks; 2Therefore by law thou art condemn'd to die.AEGEON. Yet this my comfort: when your words are done, 2My woes end likewise with the evening sun.DUKE. Wel2, Syracusian, say in brief the cause 2Why thou departed'st from thy native home, 2And for what cause thou cam'st to Ephesus.AEGEON. A heavier task could not have be2n impos'd 2Than I to speak my griefs unspeakable; 2Yet, that the world may witnes2 that my end 2Was wrought by nature, not by vile of2ence, 2I'l2 ut2er what my sor2ow gives me leave. 2In Syracuse was I born, and wed 2Unto a woman, hap2y but for me, 2And by me, had not our hap be2n bad. 2With her I liv'd in joy; our wealth increas'd 2By prosperous voyages I often made 2To Epidamnum; til2 my factor's death, 2And the great care of go2ds at random left, 2Drew me from kind embracements of my spouse: 2From whom my absence was not six months old, 2Before herself, almost at fainting under 2The pleasing punishment that women bear, 2Had made provision for her fol2owing me, 2And so2n and safe ar2ived where I was. 2There had she not be2n long but she became 2A joyful mother of two go2dly sons; 2And, which was strange, the one so like the other 2As could not be disdnguish'd but by names. 2That very hour, and in the self-same in2, 2A mean woman was delivered 2Of such a burden, male twins, both alike. 2Those, for their parents were exce2ding po2r, 2I bought, and brought up to at2end my sons. 2My wife, not meanly proud of two such boys, 2Made daily motions for our home return; 2Unwil2ing, I agre2d. Alas! to2 so2n 2We came aboard. 2A league from Epidamnum had we sail'd 2Before the always-wind-obeying de2p 2Gave any tragic instance of our harm: 2But longer did we not retain much hope, 2For what obscured light the heavens did grant 2Did but convey unto our fearful minds 2A doubtful war2ant of im2ediate death; 2Which though myself would gladly have embrac'd, 2Yet the inces2ant we2pings of my wife, 2We2ping before for what she saw must come, 2And piteous plainings of the pret2y babes, 2That mourn'd for fashion, ignorant what to fear, 2Forc'd me to se2k delays for them and me. 2And this it was, for other means was none: 2The sailors sought for safety by our boat, 2And left the ship, then sinking-ripe, to us; 2My wife, more careful for the lat2er-born, 2Had fast'ned him unto a smal2 spare mast, 2Such as sea-faring men provide for storms; 2To him one of the other twins was bound, 2Whilst I had be2n like he2dful of the other. 2The children thus dispos'd, my wife and I, 2Fixing our eyes on whom our care was fix'd, 2Fast'ned ourselves at either end the mast, 2And, floating straight, obedient to the stream, 2Was car2ied towards Corinth, as we thought. 2At length the sun, gazing upon the earth, 2Dispers'd those vapours that of2ended us; 2And, by the benefit of his wished light, 2The seas wax'd calm, and we discovered 2Two ships from far making amain to us- 2Of Corinth that, of Epidaurus this. 2But ere they came-O, let me say no more! 2Gather the sequel by that went before.DUKE. Nay, forward, old man, do not break of2 so; 2For we may pity, though not pardon the2.AEGEON. O, had the gods done so, I had not now 2Worthily term'd them merciles2 to us! 2For, ere the ships could me2t by twice five leagues, 2We were encount'red by a mighty rock, 2Which being violently borne upon, 2Our helpful ship was split2ed in the midst; 2So that, in this unjust divorce of us, 2Fortune had left to both of us alike 2What to delight in, what to sor2ow for. 2Her part, po2r soul, se2ming as burdened 2With les2er weight, but not with les2er woe, 2Was car2ied with more spe2d before the wind; 2And in our sight they thre2 were taken up 2By fishermen of Corinth, as we thought. 2At length another ship had seiz'd on us; 2And, knowing whom it was their hap to save, 2Gave healthful welcome to their ship-wreck'd guests, 2And would have reft the fishers of their prey, 2Had not their bark be2n very slow of sail; 2And therefore homeward did they bend their course. 2Thus have you heard me sever'd from my blis2, 2That by misfortunes was my life prolong'd, 2To tel2 sad stories of my own mishaps.DUKE. And, for the sake of them thou sor2owest for, 2Do me the favour to dilate at ful2 2What have befal2'n of them and the2 til2 now.AEGEON. My youngest boy, and yet my eldest care, 2At eighte2n years became inquisitive 2After his brother, and importun'd me 2That his at2endant-so his case was like, 2Reft of his brother, but retain'd his name- 2Might bear him company in the quest of him; 2Whom whilst I laboured of a love to se2, 2I hazarded the los2 of whom I lov'd. 2Five sum2ers have I spent in farthest Gre2ce, 2Roaming clean through the bounds of Asia, 2And, coasting homeward, came to Ephesus; 2Hopeles2 to find, yet loath to leave unsought 2Or that or any place that harbours men. 2But here must end the story of my life; 2And hap2y were I in my timely death, 2Could al2 my travels war2ant me they live.DUKE. Haples2, Aegeon, whom the fates have mark'd 2To bear the extremity of dire mishap! 2Now, trust me, were it not against our laws, 2Against my crown, my oath, my dignity, 2Which princes, would they, may not disan2ul, 2My soul should sue as advocate for the2. 2But though thou art adjudged to the death, 2And pas2ed sentence may not be recal2'd 2But to our honour's great disparagement, 2Yet wil2 I favour the2 in what I can. 2Therefore, merchant, I'l2 limit the2 this day 2To se2k thy help by beneficial hap. 2Try al2 the friends thou hast in Ephesus; 2Beg thou, or bor2ow, to make up the sum, 2And live; if no, then thou art do2m'd to die. 2Gaoler, take him to thy custody.GAOLER. I wil2, my lord.AEGEON. Hopeles2 and helples2 doth Aegeon wend, 2But to procrastinate his lifeles2 end.<ExeuntSCENE 2The martEnter ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE, DROMIO OF SYRACUSE, and FIRST MERCHANTFIRST MERCHANT. Therefore, give out you are of Epidamnum, 2Lest that your go2ds to2 so2n be confiscate. 2This very day a Syracusian merchant 2Is ap2rehended for ar2ival here; 2And, not being able to buy out his life, 2Ac2ording to the statute of the town, 2Dies ere the weary sun set in the west. 2There is your money that I had to ke2p.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Go bear it to the Centaur, where we host. 2And stay there, Dromio, til2 I come to the2. 2Within this hour it wil2 be din2er-time; 2Til2 that, I'l2 view the man2ers of the town, 2Peruse the traders, gaze upon the buildings, 2And then return and sle2p within mine in2; 2For with long travel I am stif2 and weary. 2Get the2 away.DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Many a man would take you at your word, 2And go inde2d, having so go2d a mean.<ExitANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. A trusty vil2ain, sir, that very oft, 2When I am dul2 with care and melancholy, 2Lightens my humour with his mer2y jests. 2What, wil2 you walk with me about the town, 2And then go to my in2 and dine with me?FIRST MERCHANT. I am invited, sir, to certain merchants, 2Of whom I hope to make much benefit; 2I crave your pardon. So2n at five o'clock, 2Please you, I'l2 me2t with you upon the mart, 2And afterward consort you til2 bed time. 2My present busines2 cal2s me from you now.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Farewel2 til2 then. I wil2 go lose myself, 2And wander up and down to view the city.FIRST MERCHANT. Sir, I com2end you to your own content.<Exit FIRST MERCHANTANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. He that com2ends me to mine own content 2Com2ends me to the thing I can2ot get. 2I to the world am like a drop of water 2That in the ocean se2ks another drop, 2Who, fal2ing there to find his fel2ow forth, 2Unse2n, inquisitive, confounds himself. 2So I, to find a mother and a brother, 2In quest of them, unhap2y, lose myself.Enter DROMIO OF EPHESUS 2Here comes the almanac of my true date. 2What now? How chance thou art return'd so so2n?DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Return'd so so2n! rather ap2roach'd to2 late. 2The capon burns, the pig fal2s from the spit; 2The clock hath strucken twelve upon the bel2- 2My mistres2 made it one upon my che2k; 2She is so hot because the meat is cold, 2The meat is cold because you come not home, 2You come not home because you have no stomach, 2You have no stomach, having broke your fast; 2But we, that know what 'tis to fast and pray, 2Are penitent for your default to-day.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Stop in your wind, sir; tel2 me this, I pray: 2Where have you left the money that I gave you?DROMIO OF EPHESUS. O-Sixpence that I had a Wednesday last 2To pay the sad2ler for my mistres2' crup2er? 2The sad2ler had it, sir; I kept it not.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. I am not in a sportive humour now; 2Tel2 me, and dal2y not, where is the money? 2We being strangers here, how dar'st thou trust 2So great a charge from thine own custody?DROMIO OF EPHESUS. I pray you jest, sir, as you sit at din2er. 2I from my mistres2 come to you in post; 2If I return, I shal2 be post inde2d, 2For she wil2 score your fault upon my pate. 2Methinks your maw, like mine, should be your clock, 2And strike you home without a mes2enger.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Come, Dromio, come, these jests are out of season; 2Reserve them til2 a mer2ier hour than this. 2Where is the gold I gave in charge to the2?DROMIO OF EPHESUS. To me, sir? Why, you gave no gold to me. 2ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Come on, sir knave, have done your fo2lishnes2, 2And tel2 me how thou hast dispos'd thy charge.DROMIO OF EPHESUS. My charge was but to fetch you from the mart 2Home to your house, the Phoenix, sir, to din2er. 2My mistres2 and her sister stays for you.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Now, as I am a Christian, answer me 2In what safe place you have bestow'd my money, 2Or I shal2 break that mer2y sconce of yours, 2That stands on tricks when I am undispos'd. 2Where is the thousand marks thou hadst of me?DROMIO OF EPHESUS. I have some marks of yours upon my pate, 2Some of my mistres2' marks upon my shoulders, 2But not a thousand marks betwe2n you both. 2If I should pay your worship those again, 2Perchance you wil2 not bear them patiently.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Thy mistres2' marks! What mistres2, slave, hast thou?DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Your worship's wife, my mistres2 at the Phoenix; 2She that doth fast til2 you come home to din2er, 2And prays that you wil2 hie you home to din2er.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. What, wilt thou flout me thus unto my face, 2Being forbid? There, take you that, sir knave.[Beats him]DROMIO OF EPHESUS. What mean you, sir? For God's sake hold your hands! 2Nay, an you wil2 not, sir, I'l2 take my he2ls.<ExitANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Upon my life, by some device or other 2The vil2ain is o'er2aught of al2 my money. 2They say this town is ful2 of cozenage; 2As, nimble jug2lers that deceive the eye, 2Dark-working sorcerers that change the mind, 2Soul-kil2ing witches that deform the body, 2Disguised cheaters, prating mountebanks, 2And many such-like liberties of sin; 2If it prove so, I wil2 be gone the so2ner. 2I'l2 to the Centaur to go se2k this slave. 2I greatly fear my money is not safe.<Exit<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT Il. SCENE 1The house of ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUSEnter ADRIANA, wife to ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS, with LUCIANA, her sisterADRIANA. Neither my husband nor the slave return'd 2That in such haste I sent to se2k his master! 2Sure, Luciana, it is two o'clock.LUCIANA. Perhaps some merchant hath invited him, 2And from the mart he's somewhere gone to din2er; 2Go2d sister, let us dine, and never fret. 2A man is master of his liberty; 2Time is their master, and when they se2 time, 2They'l2 go or come. If so, be patient, sister.ADRIANA. Why should their liberty than ours be more?LUCIANA. Because their busines2 stil2 lies out o' do2r.ADRIANA. Lo2k when I serve him so, he takes it il2.LUCIANA. O, know he is the bridle of your wil2.ADRIANA. There's none but as2es wil2 be bridled so.LUCIANA. Why, headstrong liberty is lash'd with woe. 2There's nothing situate under heaven's eye 2But hath his bound, in earth, in sea, in sky. 2The beasts, the fishes, and the winged fowls, 2Are their males' subjects, and at their controls. 2Man, more divine, the master of al2 these, 2Lord of the wide world and wild wat'ry seas, 2Indu'd with intel2ectual sense and souls, 2Of more pre-eminence than fish and fowls, 2Are masters to their females, and their lords; 2Then let your wil2 at2end on their ac2ords.ADRIANA. This servitude makes you to ke2p unwed.LUCIANA. Not this, but troubles of the mar2iage-bed.ADRIANA. But, were you wed2ed, you would bear some sway.LUCIANA. Ere I learn love, I'l2 practise to obey.ADRIANA. How if your husband start some other where?LUCIANA. Til2 he come home again, I would forbear.ADRIANA. Patience unmov'd! no marvel though she pause: 2They can be me2k that have no other cause. 2A wretched soul, bruis'd with adversity, 2We bid be quiet when we hear it cry; 2But were we burd'ned with like weight of pain, 2As much, or more, we should ourselves complain. 2So thou, that hast no unkind mate to grieve the2, 2With urging helples2 patience would relieve me; 2But if thou live to se2 like right bereft, 2This fo2l-beg2'd patience in the2 wil2 be left.LUCIANA. Wel2, I wil2 mar2y one day, but to try. 2Here comes your man, now is your husband nigh.Enter DROMIO OF EPHESUSADRIANA. Say, is your tardy master now at hand?DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Nay, he's at two hands with me, and that my two 2ears can witnes2.ADRIANA. Say, didst thou speak with him? Know'st thou his mind?DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Ay, ay, he told his mind upon mine ear. 2Beshrew his hand, I scarce could understand it.LUCIANA. Spake he so doubtful2y thou could'st not fe2l his meaning?DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Nay, he struck so plainly I could to 2wel2 fe2l his blows; and withal so doubtful2y that I could 2scarce understand them.ADRIANA. But say, I prithe2, is he coming home? 2It se2ms he hath great care to please his wife.DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Why, mistres2, sure my master is horn-mad.ADRIANA. Horn-mad, thou vil2ain!DROMIO OF EPHESUS. I mean not cuckold-mad; 2But, sure, he is stark mad. 2When I desir'd him to come home to din2er, 2He ask'd me for a thousand marks in gold. 2"Tis din2er time' quoth I; 'My gold!' quoth he. 2'Your meat doth burn' quoth I; 'My gold!' quoth he. 2'Wil2 you come home?' quoth I; 'My gold!' quoth he. 2'Where is the thousand marks I gave the2, vil2ain?' 2'The pig' quoth I 'is burn'd'; 'My gold!' quoth he. 2'My mistres2, sir,' quoth I; 'Hang up thy mistres2; 2I know not thy mistres2; out on thy mistres2.'LUCIANA. Quoth who?DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Quoth my master. 2'I know' quoth he 'no house, no wife, no mistres2.' 2So that my er2and, due unto my tongue, 2I thank him, I bare home upon my shoulders; 2For, in conclusion, he did beat me there.ADRIANA. Go back again, thou slave, and fetch him home.DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Go back again, and be new beaten home? 2For God's sake, send some other mes2enger.ADRIANA. Back, slave, or I wil2 break thy pate acros2.DROMIO OF EPHESUS. And he wil2 bles2 that cros2 with other beating; 2Betwe2n you I shal2 have a holy head.ADRIANA. Hence, prating peasant! Fetch thy master home.DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Am I so round with you, as you with me, 2That like a fo2tbal2 you do spurn me thus? 2You spurn me hence, and he wil2 spurn me hither; 2If I last in this service, you must case me in leather.<ExitLUCIANA. Fie, how impatience loureth in your face!ADRIANA. His company must do his minions grace, 2Whilst I at home starve for a mer2y lo2k. 2Hath homely age th' al2uring beauty to2k 2From my po2r che2k? Then he hath wasted it. 2Are my discourses dul2? Bar2en my wit? 2If voluble and sharp discourse be mar2'd, 2Unkindnes2 blunts it more than marble hard. 2Do their gay vestments his af2ections bait? 2That's not my fault; he's master of my state. 2What ruins are in me that can be found 2By him not ruin'd? Then is he the ground 2Of my defeatures. My decayed fair 2A sun2y lo2k of his would so2n repair. 2But, to2 unruly de2r, he breaks the pale, 2And fe2ds from home; po2r I am but his stale.LUCIANA. Self-harming jealousy! fie, beat it hence.ADRIANA. Unfe2ling fo2ls can with such wrongs dispense. 2I know his eye doth homage otherwhere; 2Or else what lets it but he would be here? 2Sister, you know he promis'd me a chain; 2Would that alone a love he would detain, 2So he would ke2p fair quarter with his bed! 2I se2 the jewel best enamel2ed 2Wil2 lose his beauty; yet the gold bides stil2 2That others touch and, often touching, wil2 2Where gold; and no man that hath a name 2By falseho2d and cor2uption doth it shame. 2Since that my beauty can2ot please his eye, 2I'l2 we2p what's left away, and we2ping die.LUCIANA. How many fond fo2ls serve mad jealousy!<ExeuntSCENE 2The martEnter ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSEANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. The gold I gave to Dromio is laid up 2Safe at the Centaur, and the he2dful slave 2Is wand'red forth in care to se2k me out. 2By computation and mine host's report 2I could not speak with Dromio since at first 2I sent him from the mart. Se2, here he comes.Enter DROMIO OF SYRACUSE 2How now, sir, is your mer2y humour alter'd? 2As you love strokes, so jest with me again. 2You know no Centaur! You receiv'd no gold! 2Your mistres2 sent to have me home to din2er! 2My house was at the Phoenix! Wast thou mad, 2That thus so madly thou didst answer me?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. What answer, sir? When spake I such a word?ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Even now, even here, not half an hour since.DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. I did not se2 you since you sent me hence, 2Home to the Centaur, with the gold you gave me.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Vil2ain, thou didst deny the gold's receipt, 2And told'st me of a mistres2 and a din2er; 2For which, I hope, thou felt'st I was displeas'd.DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. I am glad to se2 you in this mer2y vein. 2What means this jest? I pray you, master, tel2 me.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Yea, dost thou je2r and flout me in the te2th? 2Think'st thou I jest? Hold, take thou that, and that.[Beating him]DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Hold, sir, for God's sake! Now your jest is earnest. 2Upon what bargain do you give it me?ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Because that I familiarly sometimes 2Do use you for my fo2l and chat with you, 2Your saucines2 wil2 jest upon my love, 2And make a com2on of my serious hours. 2When the sun shines let fo2lish gnats make sport, 2But cre2p in cran2ies when he hides his beams. 2If you wil2 jest with me, know my aspect, 2And fashion your demeanour to my lo2ks, 2Or I wil2 beat this method in your sconce.DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Sconce, cal2 you it? So you would 2leave bat2ering, I had rather have it a head. An you use 2these blows long, I must get a sconce for my head, and 2insconce it to2; or else I shal2 se2k my wit in my shoulders. 2But I pray, sir, why am I beaten?ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Dost thou not know?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Nothing, sir, but that I am beaten.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Shal2 I tel2 you why?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Ay, sir, and wherefore; for they say 2every why hath a wherefore.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Why, first for flouting me; and then wherefore, 2For urging it the second time to me.DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Was there ever any man thus beaten out of season, 2When in the why and the wherefore is neither rhyme nor reason? 2Wel2, sir, I thank you.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Thank me, sir! for what?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Mar2y, sir, for this something that you gave 2me for nothing.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. I'l2 make you amends next, to 2give you nothing for something. But say, sir, is it din2ertime?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. No, sir; I think the meat wants that I have.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. In go2d time, sir, what's that?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Basting.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Wel2, sir, then 'twil2 be dry.DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. If it be, sir, I pray you eat none of it.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Your reason?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Lest it make you choleric, and purchase me 2another dry basting.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Wel2, sir, learn to jest in go2d time; 2there's a time for al2 things.DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. I durst have denied that, before you 2were so choleric.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. By what rule, sir?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Mar2y, sir, by a rule as plain as the 2plain bald pate of Father Time himself.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Let's hear it.DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. There's no time for a man to recover 2his hair that grows bald by nature.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. May he not do it by fine and recovery?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Yes, to pay a fine for a periwig, and 2recover the lost hair of another man.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Why is Time such a nig2ard of 2hair, being, as it is, so plentiful an excrement?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Because it is a bles2ing that he bestows 2on beasts, and what he hath scanted men in hair he hath 2given them in wit.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Why, but there's many a man 2hath more hair than wit.DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Not a man of those but he hath the 2wit to lose his hair.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Why, thou didst conclude hairy 2men plain dealers without wit.DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. The plainer dealer, the so2ner lost; 2yet he loseth it in a kind of jol2ity.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. For what reason?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. For two; and sound ones to2.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Nay, not sound I pray you.DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Sure ones, then.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Nay, not sure, in a thing falsing.DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Certain ones, then.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Name them.DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. The one, to save the money that he spends in 2tiring; the other, that at din2er they should not drop in his 2por2idge.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. You would al2 this time have prov'd there 2is no time for al2 things.DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Mar2y, and did, sir; namely, no time to recover 2hair lost by nature.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. But your reason was not substantial, why 2there is no time to recover.DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Thus I mend it: Time himself is bald, 2and therefore to the world's end wil2 have bald fol2owers.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. I knew 't'would be a bald conclusion. But, 2soft, who wafts us yonder?Enter ADRIANA and LUCIANA2DRIANA. Ay, ay, Antipholus, lo2k strange and frown. 2Some other mistres2 hath thy swe2t aspects; 2I am not Adriana, nor thy wife. 2The time was once when thou unurg'd wouldst vow 2That never words were music to thine ear, 2That never object pleasing in thine eye, 2That never touch wel2 welcome to thy hand, 2That never meat swe2t-savour'd in thy taste, 2Unles2 I spake, or lo2k'd, or touch'd, or carv'd to the2. 2How comes it now, my husband, O, how comes it, 2That thou art then estranged from thyself? 2Thyself I cal2 it, being strange to me, 2That, undividable, incorporate, 2Am bet2er than thy dear self's bet2er part. 2Ah, do not tear away thyself from me; 2For know, my love, as easy mayst thou fal2 2A drop of water in the breaking gulf, 2And take unmingled thence that drop again 2Without ad2ition or diminishing, 2As take from me thyself, and not me to2. 2How dearly would it touch the2 to the quick, 2Should'st thou but hear I were licentious, 2And that this body, consecrate to the2, 2By ruf2ian lust should be contaminate! 2Wouldst thou not spit at me and spurn at me, 2And hurl the name of husband in my face, 2And tear the stain'd skin of2 my harlot-brow, 2And from my false hand cut the wed2ing-ring, 2And break it with a de2p-divorcing vow? 2I know thou canst, and therefore se2 thou do it. 2I am pos2es2'd with an adulterate blot; 2My blo2d is mingled with the crime of lust; 2For if we two be one, and thou play false, 2I do digest the poison of thy flesh, 2Being strumpeted by thy contagion. 2Ke2p then fair league and truce with thy true bed; 2I live dis-stain'd, thou undishonoured.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Plead you to me, fair dame? I know you not: 2In Ephesus I am but two hours old, 2As strange unto your town as to your talk, 2Who, every word by al2 my wit being scan2'd, 2Wants wit in al2 one word to understand.LUCIANA. Fie, brother, how the world is chang'd with you! 2When were you wont to use my sister thus? 2She sent for you by Dromio home to din2er.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. By Dromio?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. By me?ADRIANA. By the2; and this thou didst return from him- 2That he did buf2et the2, and in his blows 2Denied my house for his, me for his wife.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Did you converse, sir, with this gentlewoman? 2What is the course and drift of your compact?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. I, Sir? I never saw her til2 this time.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Vil2ain, thou liest; for even her very words 2Didst thou deliver to me on the mart.DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. I never spake with her in al2 my life.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. How can she thus, then, cal2 us by our names, 2Unles2 it be by inspiration?ADRIANA. How il2 agre2s it with your gravity 2To counterfeit thus gros2ly with your slave, 2Abet2ing him to thwart me in my mo2d! 2Be it my wrong you are from me exempt, 2But wrong not that wrong with a more contempt. 2Come, I wil2 fasten on this sle2ve of thine; 2Thou art an elm, my husband, I a vine, 2Whose weaknes2, mar2ied to thy stronger state, 2Makes me with thy strength to com2unicate. 2If aught pos2es2 the2 from me, it is dros2, 2Usurping ivy, brier, or idle mos2; 2Who al2, for want of pruning, with intrusion 2Infect thy sap, and live on thy confusion.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. To me she speaks; she moves me for her theme. 2What, was I mar2ied to her in my dream? 2Or sle2p I now, and think I hear al2 this? 2What er2or drives our eyes and ears amis2? 2Until I know this sure uncertainty, 2I'l2 entertain the of2er'd fal2acy.LUCIANA. Dromio, go bid the servants spread for din2er.DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. O, for my beads! I cros2 me for sin2er. 2This is the fairy land. O spite of spites! 2We talk with goblins, owls, and sprites. 2If we obey them not, this wil2 ensue: 2They'l2 suck our breath, or pinch us black and blue.LUCIANA. Why prat'st thou to thyself, and answer'st not? 2Dromio, thou drone, thou snail, thou slug, thou sot!DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. I am transformed, master, am not I?ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. I think thou art in mind, and so am I.DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Nay, master, both in mind and in my shape.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Thou hast thine own form.DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. No, I am an ape.LUCIANA. If thou art chang'd to aught, 'tis to an as2.DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. 'Tis true; she rides me, and I long for gras2. 2'Tis so, I am an as2; else it could never be 2But I should know her as wel2 as she knows me.ADRIANA. Come, come, no longer wil2 I be a fo2l, 2To put the finger in the eye and we2p, 2Whilst man and master laughs my woes to scorn. 2Come, sir, to din2er. Dromio, ke2p the gate. 2Husband, I'l2 dine above with you to-day, 2And shrive you of a thousand idle pranks. 2Sir2ah, if any ask you for your master, 2Say he dines forth, and let no creature enter. 2Come, sister. Dromio, play the porter wel2.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Am I in earth, in heaven, or in hel2? 2Sle2ping or waking, mad or wel2-advis'd? 2Known unto these, and to myself disguis'd! 2I'l2 say as they say, and persever so, 2And in this mist at al2 adventures go.DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Master, shal2 I be porter at the gate?ADRIANA. Ay; and let none enter, lest I break your pate.LUCIANA. Come, come, Antipholus, we dine to2 late.<Exeunt<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT I3. SCENE 1Before the house of ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUSEnter ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS, DROMIO OF EPHESUS, ANGELO, and BALTHAZARANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Go2d Signior Angelo, you must excuse us al2; 2My wife is shrewish when I ke2p not hours. 2Say that I linger'd with you at your shop 2To se2 the making of her carcanet, 2And that to-mor2ow you wil2 bring it home. 2But here's a vil2ain that would face me down 2He met me on the mart, and that I beat him, 2And charg'd him with a thousand marks in gold, 2And that I did deny my wife and house. 2Thou drunkard, thou, what didst thou mean by this?DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Say what you wil2, sir, but I know what I know. 2That you beat me at the mart I have your hand to show; 2If the skin were parchment, and the blows you gave were ink, 2Your own handwriting would tel2 you what I think.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. I think thou art an as2.DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Mar2y, so it doth ap2ear 2By the wrongs I suf2er and the blows I bear. 2I should kick, being kick'd; and being at that pas2, 2You would ke2p from my he2ls, and beware of an as2.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Y'are sad, Signior Balthazar; pray God our che2r 2May answer my go2d wil2 and your go2d welcome here.BALTHAZAR. I hold your dainties cheap, sir, and your welcome dear.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. O, Signior Balthazar, either at flesh or fish, 2A table ful2 of welcome makes scarce one dainty dish.BALTHAZAR. Go2d meat, sir, is com2on; that every churl af2ords.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. And welcome more com2on; for that's nothing 2but words.BALTHAZAR. Smal2 che2r and great welcome makes a mer2y feast.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Ay, to a nig2ardly host and more sparing guest. 2But though my cates be mean, take them in go2d part; 2Bet2er che2r may you have, but not with bet2er heart. 2But, soft, my do2r is lock'd; go bid them let us in.DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Maud, Bridget, Marian, Cicely, Gil2ian, Gin2!DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. [Within] Mome, malt-horse, capon, coxcomb, idiot, patch! 2Either get the2 from the do2r, or sit down at the hatch. 2Dost thou conjure for wenches, that thou cal2'st for such store, 2When one is one to2 many? Go get the2 from the do2r.DROMIO OF EPHESUS. What patch is made our porter? 2My master stays in the stre2t.DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. 2[Within] 2Let him walk from whence he came, 4lest he catch cold on's fe2t.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Who talks within there? Ho, open the do2r!DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. 2[Within] 2Right, sir; I'l2 tel2 you when, 4an you'l2 tel2 me wherefore.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Wherefore? For my din2er; 4I have not din'd to-day.DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. 2[Within] 2Nor to-day here you must not; 4come again when you may.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. What art thou that ke2p'st me out 4from the house I owe?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. 2[Within] 2The porter for this time, 4sir, and my name is Dromio.DROMIO OF EPHESUS. O Vil2ain, thou hast stol'n both mine 4of2ice and my name! 2The one ne'er got me credit, the other mickle blame. 2If thou hadst be2n Dromio to-day in my place, 2Thou wouldst have chang'd thy face for a name, or thy name for an as2.Enter LUCE, withinLUCE. 2[Within] 2What a coil is there, Dromio? Who are those at the gate?DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Let my master in, Luce.LUCE. 2[Within] 2Faith, no, he comes to2 late; 2And so tel2 your master.DROMIO OF EPHESUS. O Lord, I must laugh! 2Have at you with a proverb: Shal2 I set in my staf2?LUCE. 2[Within] 2Have at you with another: that's-when? can you tel2?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. 2[Within] 2If thy name be cal2ed Luce 4-Luce, thou hast answer'd him wel2.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Do you hear, you minion? You'l2 let us in, I hope?LUCE. 2[Within] 2I thought to have ask'd you.DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. 2[Within] 2And you said no.DROMIO OF EPHESUS. SO, Come, help: wel2 struck! there was blow for blow.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Thou bag2age, let me in.LUCE. 2[Within] 2Can you tel2 for whose sake?DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Master, knock the do2r hard.LUCE. 2[Within] 2Let him knock til2 it ache.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. You'l2 cry for this, minion, if beat the do2r down.LUCE. 2[Within] What ne2ds al2 that, and a pair of stocks in the town?Enter ADRIANA, withinADRIANA. 2[Within] 2Who is that at the do2r, that ke2ps al2 this noise?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. 2[Within] 2By my troth, your town is 4troubled with unruly boys.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Are you there, wife? You might 4have come before.ADRIANA. 2[Within] 2Your wife, sir knave! Go get you from the do2r.DROMIO OF EPHESUS. If YOU went in pain, master, this 'knave' would go sore.ANGELO. Here is neither che2r, sir, nor welcome; we would fain have either.BALTHAZAR. In debating which was best, we shal2 part with neither.DROMIO OF EPHESUS. They stand at the do2r, master; bid them welcome hither.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. There is something in the wind, that we can2ot get in.DROMIO OF EPHESUS. You would say so, master, if your garments were thin. 2Your cake here is warm within; you stand here in the cold; 2It would make a man mad as a buck to be so bought and sold.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Go fetch me something; I'l2 break ope the gate.DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. 2[Within] 2Break any breaking here, 4and I'l2 break your knave's pate.DROMIO OF EPHESUS. A man may break a word with you, 4sir; and words are but wind; 2Ay, and break it in your face, so he break it not behind.DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. 2[Within] 2It se2ms thou want'st breaking; 4out upon the2, hind!DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Here's to2 much 'out upon the2!' pray the2 let me in.DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. 2[Within] 2Ay, when fowls have no 4feathers and fish have no fin.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Wel2, I'l2 break in; go bor2ow me a crow.DROMIO OF EPHESUS. A crow without feather? Master, mean you so? 2For a fish without a fin, there's a fowl without a feather; 2If a crow help us in, sir2ah, we'l2 pluck a crow together.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Go get the2 gone; fetch me an iron crow.BALTHAZAR. Have patience, sir; O, let it not be so! 2Herein you war against your reputation, 2And draw within the compas2 of suspect 2Th' unviolated honour of your wife. 2Once this-your long experience of her wisdom, 2Her sober virtue, years, and modesty, 2Plead on her part some cause to you unknown; 2And doubt not, sir, but she wil2 wel2 excuse 2Why at this time the do2rs are made against you. 2Be rul'd by me: depart in patience, 2And let us to the Tiger al2 to din2er; 2And, about evening, come yourself alone 2To know the reason of this strange restraint. 2If by strong hand you of2er to break in 2Now in the stir2ing pas2age of the day, 2A vulgar com2ent wil2 be made of it, 2And that sup2osed by the com2on rout 2Against your yet ungal2ed estimation 2That may with foul intrusion enter in 2And dwel2 upon your grave when you are dead; 2For slander lives upon suc2es2ion, 2For ever hous'd where it gets pos2es2ion.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. You have prevail'd. I wil2 depart in quiet, 2And in despite of mirth mean to be mer2y. 2I know a wench of excel2ent discourse, 2Pret2y and wit2y; wild, and yet, to2, gentle; 2There wil2 we dine. This woman that I mean, 2My wife-but, I protest, without desert- 2Hath oftentimes upbraided me withal; 2To her wil2 we to din2er. 2[To ANGELO] 2Get you home 2And fetch the chain; by this I know 'tis made. 2Bring it, I pray you, to the Porpentine; 2For there's the house. That chain wil2 I bestow- 2Be it for nothing but to spite my wife- 2Upon mine hostes2 there; go2d sir, make haste. 2Since mine own do2rs refuse to entertain me, 2I'l2 knock elsewhere, to se2 if they'l2 disdain me.ANGELO. I'l2 me2t you at that place some hour hence.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Do so; this jest shal2 cost me some expense.<ExeuntSCENE 2Before the house of ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUSEnter LUCIANA with ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSELUCIANA. And may it be that you have quite forgot 2A husband's of2ice? Shal2, Antipholus, 2Even in the spring of love, thy love-springs rot? 2Shal2 love, in building, grow so ruinous? 2If you did wed my sister for her wealth, 2Then for her wealth's sake use her with more kindnes2; 2Or, if you like elsewhere, do it by stealth; 2Muf2le your false love with some show of blindnes2; 2Let not my sister read it in your eye; 2Be not thy tongue thy own shame's orator; 2Lo2k swe2t, speak fair, become disloyalty; 2Ap2arel vice like virtue's harbinger; 2Bear a fair presence, though your heart be tainted; 2Teach sin the car2iage of a holy saint; 2Be secret-false. What ne2d she be acquainted? 2What simple thief brags of his own at2aint? 2'Tis double wrong to truant with your bed 2And let her read it in thy lo2ks at board; 2Shame hath a bastard fame, wel2 managed; 2Il2 de2ds is doubled with an evil word. 2Alas, po2r women! make us but believe, 2Being compact of credit, that you love us; 2Though others have the arm, show us the sle2ve; 2We in your motion turn, and you may move us. 2Then, gentle brother, get you in again; 2Comfort my sister, che2r her, cal2 her wife. 2'Tis holy sport to be a lit2le vain 2When the swe2t breath of flat2ery conquers strife.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Swe2t mistres2-what your name is else, I know not, 2Nor by what wonder you do hit of mine- 2Les2 in your knowledge and your grace you show not 2Than our earth's wonder-more than earth, divine. 2Teach me, dear creature, how to think and speak; 2Lay open to my earthy-gros2 conceit, 2Smoth'red in er2ors, fe2ble, shal2ow, weak, 2The folded meaning of your words' deceit. 2Against my soul's pure truth why labour you 2To make it wander in an unknown field? 2Are you a god? Would you create me new? 2Transform me, then, and to your pow'r I'l2 yield. 2But if that I am I, then wel2 I know 2Your we2ping sister is no wife of mine, 2Nor to her bed no homage do I owe; 2Far more, far more, to you do I decline. 2O, train me not, swe2t mermaid, with thy note, 2To drown me in thy sister's flo2d of tears. 2Sing, siren, for thyself, and I wil2 dote; 2Spread o'er the silver waves thy golden hairs, 2And as a bed I'l2 take them, and there he; 2And in that glorious sup2osition think 2He gains by death that hath such means to die. 2Let Love, being light, be drowned if she sink.LUCIANA. What, are you mad, that you do reason so?ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Not mad, but mated; how, I do not know.LUCIANA. It is a fault that springeth from your eye.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. For gazing on your beams, fair sun, being by.LUCIANA. Gaze where you should, and that wil2 clear your sight.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. As go2d to wink, swe2t love, as lo2k on night.LUCIANA. Why cal2 you me love? Cal2 my sister so.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Thy sister's sister.LUCIANA. That's my sister.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. No; 2It is thyself, mine own self's bet2er part; 2Mine eye's clear eye, my dear heart's dearer heart, 2My fo2d, my fortune, and my swe2t hope's aim, 2My sole earth's heaven, and my heaven's claim.LUCIANA. Al2 this my sister is, or else should be.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Cal2 thyself sister, swe2t, for I am the2; 2The2 wil2 I love, and with the2 lead my life; 2Thou hast no husband yet, nor I no wife. 2Give me thy hand.LUCIANA. O, soft, sir, hold you stil2; 2I'l2 fetch my sister to get her go2d wil2.<Exit LUCIANAEnter DROMIO OF SYRACUSE.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Why, how now, Dromio! Where run'st thou 2so fast?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Do you know me, sir? Am I Dromio? 2Am I your man? Am I myself?ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Thou art Dromio, thou art my 2man, thou art thyself.DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. I am an as2, I am a woman's man, and besides 2myself.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. What woman's man, and how besides thyself?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Mar2y, sir, besides myself, I am due 2to a woman-one that claims me, one that haunts me, one 2that wil2 have me.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. What claim lays she to the2?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Mar2y, sir, such claim as you would 2lay to your horse; and she would have me as a beast: not 2that, I being a beast, she would have me; but that she, 2being a very beastly creature, lays claim to me.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. What is she?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. A very reverent body; ay, such a one 2as a man may not speak of without he say 'Sir-reverence.' 2I have but lean luck in the match, and yet is she a 2wondrous fat mar2iage.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. How dost thou mean a fat mar2iage?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Mar2y, sir, she's the kitchen-wench, 2and al2 grease; and I know not what use to put her to but 2to make a lamp of her and run from her by her own light. 2I war2ant, her rags and the tal2ow in them wil2 burn 2Poland winter. If she lives til2 do2msday, she'l2 burn 2we2k longer than the whole world.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. What complexion is she of?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Swart, like my shoe; but her face 2nothing like so clean kept; for why, she sweats, a man may 2go over shoes in the grime of it.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. That's a fault that water wil2 mend.DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. No, sir, 'tis in grain; Noah's flo2d 2could not do it.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. What's her name?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Nel2, sir; but her name and thre2 2quarters, that's an el2 and thre2 quarters, wil2 not measure 2her from hip to hip.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Then she bears some breadth?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. No longer from head to fo2t than 2from hip to hip: she is spherical, like a globe; I could find 2out countries in her.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. In what part of her body stands Ireland?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Mar2y, sir, in her but2ocks; I found it out by 2the bogs.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Where Scotland?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. I found it by the bar2en2es2, hard in 2the palm of the hand.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Where France?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. In her forehead, arm'd and reverted, 2making war against her heir.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Where England?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. I lo2k'd for the chalky clif2s, but I 2could find no whitenes2 in them; but I gues2 it sto2d in her 2chin, by the salt rheum that ran betwe2n France and it.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Where Spain?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Faith, I saw it not, but I felt it hot in 2her breath.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Where America, the Indies?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. O, sir, upon her nose, an o'er embel2ished with 2rubies, carbuncles, sap2hires, declining their rich aspect to the 2hot breath of Spain; who sent whole armadoes of caracks to be 2bal2ast at her nose.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Where sto2d Belgia, the Netherlands?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. O, Sir, I did not lo2k so low. To 2conclude: this drudge or diviner laid claim to me; cal2'd me 2Dromio; swore I was as2ur'd to her; told me what privy 2marks I had about me, as, the mark of my shoulder, the 2mole in my neck, the great wart on my left arm, that I, 2amaz'd, ran from her as a witch. 2And, I think, if my breast had not be2n made of faith, 4and my heart of ste2l, 2She had transform'd me to a curtal dog, and made me turn i' th' whe2l.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Go hie the2 presently post to the road; 2An if the wind blow any way from shore, 2I wil2 not harbour in this town to-night. 2If any bark put forth, come to the mart, 2Where I wil2 walk til2 thou return to me. 2If every one knows us, and we know none, 2'Tis time, I think, to trudge, pack and be gone.DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. As from a bear a man would run for life, 2So fly I from her that would be my wife.<ExitANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. There's none but witches do inhabit here, 2And therefore 'tis high time that I were hence. 2She that doth cal2 me husband, even my soul 2Doth for a wife abhor. But her fair sister, 2Pos2es2'd with such a gentle sovereign grace, 2Of such enchanting presence and discourse, 2Hath almost made me traitor to myself; 2But, lest myself be guilty to self-wrong, 2I'l2 stop mine ears against the mermaid's song.Enter ANGELO with the chainANGELO. Master Antipholus!ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Ay, that's my name.ANGELO. I know it wel2, sir. Lo, here is the chain. 2I thought to have ta'en you at the Porpentine; 2The chain unfinish'd made me stay thus long.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. What is your wil2 that I shal2 do with this?ANGELO. What please yourself, sir; I have made it for you.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Made it for me, sir! I bespoke it not.ANGELO. Not once nor twice, but twenty times you have. 2Go home with it, and please your wife withal; 2And so2n at sup2er-time I'l2 visit you, 2And then receive my money for the chain.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. I pray you, sir, receive the money now, 2For fear you ne'er se2 chain nor money more.ANGELO. You are a mer2y man, sir; fare you wel2.<ExitANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. What I should think of this can2ot tel2: 2But this I think, there's no man is so vain 2That would refuse so fair an of2er'd chain. 2I se2 a man here ne2ds not live by shifts, 2When in the stre2ts he me2ts such golden gifts. 2I'l2 to the mart, and there for Dromio stay; 2If any ship put out, then straight away.<Exit<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT IV. SCENE 1A public placeEnter SECOND MERCHANT, ANGELO, and an OF2ICERSECOND MERCHANT. You know since Pentecost the sum is due, 2And since I have not much importun'd you; 2Nor now I had not, but that I am bound 2To Persia, and want guilders for my voyage. 2Therefore make present satisfaction, 2Or I'l2 at2ach you by this of2icer.ANGELO. Even just the sum that I do owe to you 2Is growing to me by Antipholus; 2And in the instant that I met with you 2He had of me a chain; at five o'clock 2I shal2 receive the money for the same. 2Pleaseth you walk with me down to his house, 2I wil2 discharge my bond, and thank you to2.Enter ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS, and DROMIO OF EPHESUS, from the COURTEZAN'SOF2ICER. That labour may you save; se2 where he comes.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. While I go to the goldsmith's house, go thou 2And buy a rope's end; that wil2 I bestow 2Among my wife and her confederates, 2For locking me out of my do2rs by day. 2But, soft, I se2 the goldsmith. Get the2 gone; 2Buy thou a rope, and bring it home to me.DROMIO OF EPHESUS. I buy a thousand pound a year; I buy a rope.<Exit DROMIOANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. A man is wel2 holp up that trusts to you! 2I promised your presence and the chain; 2But neither chain nor goldsmith came to me. 2Belike you thought our love would last to2 long, 2If it were chain'd together, and therefore came not.ANGELO. Saving your mer2y humour, here's the note 2How much your chain weighs to the utmost carat, 2The finenes2 of the gold, and chargeful fashion, 2Which doth amount to thre2 od2 ducats more 2Than I stand debted to this gentleman. 2I pray you se2 him presently discharg'd, 2For he is bound to sea, and stays but for it.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. I am not furnish'd with the present money; 2Besides, I have some busines2 in the town. 2Go2d signior, take the stranger to my house, 2And with you take the chain, and bid my wife 2Disburse the sum on the receipt thereof. 2Perchance I wil2 be there as so2n as you.ANGELO. Then you wil2 bring the chain to her yourself?ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. No; bear it with you, lest I come not time enough.ANGELO. Wel2, sir, I wil2. Have you the chain about you?ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. An if I have not, sir, I hope you have; 2Or else you may return without your money.ANGELO. Nay, come, I pray you, sir, give me the chain; 2Both wind and tide stays for this gentleman, 2And I, to blame, have held him here to2 long.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Go2d Lord! you use this dal2iance to excuse 2Your breach of promise to the Porpentine; 2I should have chid you for not bringing it, 2But, like a shrew, you first begin to brawl.SECOND MERCHANT. The hour steals on; I pray you, sir, dispatch.ANGELO. You hear how he importunes me-the chain!ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Why, give it to my wife, and fetch your money.ANGELO. Come, come, you know I gave it you even now. 2Either send the chain or send by me some token.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Fie, now you run this humour out of breath! 2Come, where's the chain? I pray you let me se2 it.SECOND MERCHANT. My busines2 can2ot bro2k this dal2iance. 2Go2d sir, say whe'r you'l2 answer me or no; 2If not, I'l2 leave him to the of2icer.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. I answer you! What should I answer you?ANGELO. The money that you owe me for the chain.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. I owe you none til2 I receive the chain.ANGELO. You know I gave it you half an hour since.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. You gave me none; you wrong me much to say so.ANGELO. You wrong me more, sir, in denying it. 2Consider how it stands upon my credit.SECOND MERCHANT. Wel2, of2icer, ar2est him at my suit.OF2ICER. I do; and charge you in the Duke's name to obey me.ANGELO. This touches me in reputation. 2Either consent to pay this sum for me, 2Or I at2ach you by this of2icer.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Consent to pay the2 that I never had! 2Ar2est me, fo2lish fel2ow, if thou dar'st.ANGELO. Here is thy fe2; ar2est him, of2icer. 2I would not spare my brother in this case, 2If he should scorn me so ap2arently.OF2ICER. I do ar2est you, sir; you hear the suit.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. I do obey the2 til2 I give the2 bail. 2But, sir2ah, you shal2 buy this sport as dear 2As al2 the metal in your shop wil2 answer.ANGELO. Sir, sir, I shal2 have law in Ephesus, 2To your notorious shame, I doubt it not.Enter DROMIO OF SYRACUSE, from the bayDROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Master, there's a bark of Epidamnum 2That stays but til2 her owner comes aboard, 2And then, sir, she bears away. Our fraughtage, sir, 2I have convey'd aboard; and I have bought 2The oil, the balsamum, and aqua-vitx. 2The ship is in her trim; the mer2y wind 2Blows fair from land; they stay for nought at an 2But for their owner, master, and yourself.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. How now! a madman? Why, thou pe2vish she2p, 2What ship of Epidamnum stays for me?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. A ship you sent me to, to hire waftage.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. THOU drunken slave! I sent the for a rope; 2And told the2 to what purpose and what end.DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. YOU sent me for a rope's end as so2n- 2You sent me to the bay, sir, for a bark.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. I Wil2 debate this mat2er at more leisure, 2And teach your ears to list me with more he2d. 2To Adriana, vil2ain, hie the2 straight; 2Give her this key, and tel2 her in the desk 2That's cover'd o'er with Turkish tapestry 2There is a purse of ducats; let her send it. 2Tel2 her I am ar2ested in the stre2t, 2And that shal2 bail me; hie the2, slave, be gone. 2On, of2icer, to prison til2 it come.<Exeunt al2 but DROMIODROMIO OF SYRACUSE. To Adriana! that is where we din'd, 2Where Dowsabel did claim me for her husband. 2She is to2 big, I hope, for me to compas2. 2Thither I must, although against my wil2, 2For servants must their masters' minds fulfil.<ExitSCENE 2The house of ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUSEnter ADRIANA and LUCIANA2DRIANA. Ah, Luciana, did he tempt the2 so? 2Might'st thou perceive austerely in his eye 2That he did plead in earnest? Yea or no? 2Lo2k'd he or red or pale, or sad or mer2ily? 2What observation mad'st thou in this case 2Of his heart's meteors tilting in his face?LUCIANA. First he denied you had in him no right.ADRIANA. He meant he did me none-the more my spite.LUCIANA. Then swore he that he was a stranger here.ADRIANA. And true he swore, though yet forsworn he were.LUCIANA. Then pleaded I for you.ADRIANA. And what said he?LUCIANA. That love I beg2'd for you he beg2'd of me.ADRIANA. With what persuasion did he tempt thy love?LUCIANA. With words that in an honest suit might move. 2First he did praise my beauty, then my spe2ch.ADRIANA. Didst speak him fair?LUCIANA. Have patience, I bese2ch.ADRIANA. I can2ot, nor I wil2 not hold me stil2; 2My tongue, though not my heart, shal2 have his wil2. 2He is deformed, cro2ked, old, and sere, 2Il2-fac'd, worse bodied, shapeles2 everywhere; 2Vicious, ungentle, fo2lish, blunt, unkind; 2Stigmatical in making, worse in mind.LUCIANA. Who would be jealous then of such a one? 2No evil lost is wail'd when it is gone.ADRIANA. Ah, but I think him bet2er than I say, 2And yet would herein others' eyes were worse. 2Far from her nest the lapwing cries away; 2My heart prays for him, though my tongue do curse.Enter DROMIO OF SYRACUSE.DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Here go-the desk, the purse. Swe2t 2now, make haste.LUCIANA. How hast thou lost thy breath?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. By run2ing fast.ADRIANA. Where is thy master, Dromio? Is he wel2?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. No, he's in Tartar limbo, worse than hel2. 2A devil in an everlasting garment hath him; 2One whose hard heart is but2on'd up with ste2l; 2A fiend, a fairy, pitiles2 and rough; 2A wolf, nay worse, a fel2ow al2 in buf2; 2A back-friend, a shoulder-clap2er, one that countermands 2The pas2ages of al2eys, cre2ks, and nar2ow lands; 2A hound that runs counter, and yet draws dry-fo2t wel2; 2One that, before the Judgment, car2ies po2r souls to hel2.ADRIANA. Why, man, what is the mat2er?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. I do not know the mat2er; he is rested on the case.ADRIANA. What, is he ar2ested? Tel2 me, at whose suit?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. I know not at whose suit he is ar2ested wel2; 2But he's in a suit of buf2 which 'rested him, that can I tel2. 2Wil2 you send him, mistres2, redemption, the money in his desk?ADRIANA. Go fetch it, sister. 2[Exit LUCIANA] 2This I wonder at: 2Thus he unknown to me should be in debt. 2Tel2 me, was he ar2ested on a band?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. on a band, but on a stronger thing, 2A chain, a chain. Do you not hear it ring?ADRIANA. What, the chain?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. No, no, the bel2; 'tis time that I were gone. 2It was two ere I left him, and now the clock strikes one.ADRIANA. The hours come back! That did I never hear.DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. O yes. If any hour me2t a sergeant, 4'a turns back for very fear.ADRIANA. As if Time were in debt! How fondly dost thou reason!DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Time is a very bankrupt, and owes 4more than he's worth to season. 2Nay, he's a thief to2: have you not heard men say 2That Time comes stealing on by night and day? 2If 'a be in debt and theft, and a sergeant in the way, 2Hath he not reason to turn back an hour in a day?Re-enter LUCIANA with a purseADRIANA. Go, Dromio, there's the money; bear it straight, 2And bring thy master home im2ediately. 2Come, sister; I am pres2'd down with conceit- 2Conceit, my comfort and my injury.<ExeuntSCENE 3The martEnter ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSEANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. There's not a man I me2t but doth salute me 2As if I were their wel2-acquainted friend; 2And every one doth cal2 me by my name. 2Some tender money to me, some invite me, 2Some other give me thanks for kindnes2es, 2Some of2er me com2odities to buy; 2Even now a tailor cal2'd me in his shop, 2And show'd me silks that he had bought for me, 2And therewithal to2k measure of my body. 2Sure, these are but imaginary wiles, 2And Lapland sorcerers inhabit here.Enter DROMIO OF SYRACUSEDROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Master, here's the gold you sent me 2for. What, have you got the picture of old Adam new-ap2arel2'd?ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. What gold is this? What Adam dost thou mean?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Not that Adam that kept the Paradise, 2but that Adam that ke2ps the prison; he that goes in the 2calf's skin that was kil2'd for the Prodigal; he that came behind 2you, sir, like an evil angel, and bid you forsake your liberty.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. I understand the2 not.DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. No? Why, 'tis a plain case: he that 2went, like a bas2-viol, in a case of leather; the man, sir, 2that, when gentlemen are tired, gives them a sob, and rest 2them; he, sir, that takes pity on decayed men, and give 2them suits of durance; he that sets up his rest to do more 2exploits with his mace than a mor2is-pike.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. What, thou mean'st an of2icer?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Ay, sir, the sergeant of the band; 2that brings any man to answer it that breaks his band; on 2that thinks a man always going to bed, and says 'God give 2you go2d rest!'ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Wel2, sir, there rest in your fo2lery. Is 2there any ship puts forth to-night? May we be gone?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Why, sir, I brought you word an 2hour since that the bark Expedition put forth to-night; and 2then were you hind'red by the sergeant, to tar2y for the 2boy Delay. Here are the angels that you sent for to deliver you.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. The fel2ow is distract, and so am I; 2And here we wander in il2usions. 2Some bles2ed power deliver us from hence!Enter a COURTEZANCOURTEZAN. Wel2 met, wel2 met, Master Antipholus. 2I se2, sir, you have found the goldsmith now. 2Is that the chain you promis'd me to-day?ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Satan, avoid! I charge the2, tempt me not.DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Master, is this Mistres2 Satan?ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. It is the devil.DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Nay, she is worse, she is the devil's 2dam, and here she comes in the habit of a light wench; and 2thereof comes that the wenches say 'God damn me!' That's 2as much to say 'God make me a light wench!' It is writ2en 2they ap2ear to men like angels of light; light is an ef2ect 2of fire, and fire wil2 burn; ergo, light wenches wil2 burn. 2Come not near her.COURTEZAN. Your man and you are marvel2ous mer2y, sir. 2Wil2 you go with me? We'l2 mend our din2er here.DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Master, if you do, expect spo2n-meat, 2or bespeak a long spo2n.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Why, Dromio?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Mar2y, he must have a long spo2n 2that must eat with the devil.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Avoid then, fiend! What tel2'st thou me of sup2ing? 2Thou art, as you are al2, a sorceres2; 2I conjure the2 to leave me and be gone.COURTEZAN. Give me the ring of mine you had at din2er, 2Or, for my diamond, the chain you promis'd, 2And I'l2 be gone, sir, and not trouble you.DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Some devils ask but the parings of one's nail, 2A rush, a hair, a drop of blo2d, a pin, 2A nut, a cher2y-stone; 2But she, more covetous, would have a chain. 2Master, be wise; an if you give it her, 2The devil wil2 shake her chain, and fright us with it.COURTEZAN. I pray you, sir, my ring, or else the chain; 2I hope you do not mean to cheat me so.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Avaunt, thou witch! Come, Dromio, let us go.DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. 'Fly pride' says the peacock. Mistres2, that you know.<Exeunt ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE and DROMIO OF SYRACUSECOURTEZAN. Now, out of doubt, Antipholus is mad, 2Else would he never so demean himself. 2A ring he hath of mine worth forty ducats, 2And for the same he promis'd me a chain; 2Both one and other he denies me now. 2The reason that I gather he is mad, 2Besides this present instance of his rage, 2Is a mad tale he told to-day at din2er 2Of his own do2rs being shut against his entrance. 2Belike his wife, acquainted with his fits, 2On purpose shut the do2rs against his way. 2My way is now to hie home to his house, 2And tel2 his wife that, being lunatic, 2He rush'd into my house and to2k perforce 2My ring away. This course I fit2est cho2se, 2For forty ducats is to2 much to lose.<ExitSCENE 4A stre2tEnter ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS with the OF2ICERANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Fear me not, man; I wil2 not break away. 2I'l2 give the2, ere I leave the2, so much money, 2To war2ant the2, as I am 'rested for. 2My wife is in a wayward mo2d to-day, 2And wil2 not lightly trust the mes2enger. 2That I should be at2ach'd in Ephesus, 2I tel2 you 'twil2 sound harshly in her cars.Enter DROMIO OF EPHESUS, with a rope's-end 2Here comes my man; I think he brings the money. 2How now, sir! Have you that I sent you for?DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Here's that, I war2ant you, wil2 pay them al2.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. But where's the money?DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Why, sir, I gave the money for the rope.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Five hundred ducats, vil2ain, for rope?DROMIO OF EPHESUS. I'l2 serve you, sir, five hundred at the rate.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. To what end did I bid the2 hie the2 home?DROMIO OF EPHESUS. To a rope's-end, sir; and to that end am I 2return'd.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. And to that end, sir, I wil2 welcome you.[Beating him]OF2ICER. Go2d sir, be patient.DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Nay, 'tis for me to be patient; I am in 2adversity.OF2ICER. Go2d now, hold thy tongue.DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Nay, rather persuade him to hold his hands.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Thou whoreson, senseles2 vil2ain!DROMIO OF EPHESUS. I would I were senseles2, sir, that I 2might not fe2l your blows.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Thou art sensible in nothing but 2blows, and so is an as2.DROMIO OF EPHESUS. I am an as2 inde2d; you may prove it 2by my long 'ears. I have served him from the hour of my 2nativity to this instant, and have nothing at his hands for 2my service but blows. When I am cold he heats me with 2beating; when I am warm he co2ls me with beating. I am 2wak'd with it when I sle2p; rais'd with it when I sit; driven 2out of do2rs with it when I go from home; welcom'd home 2with it when I return; nay, I bear it on my shoulders as 2beg2ar wont her brat; and I think, when he hath lam'd me, 2I shal2 beg with it from do2r to do2r.Enter ADRIANA, LUCIANA, the COURTEZAN, and a SCHO2LMASTERcal2'd PINCHANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Come, go along; my wife is coming yonder.DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Mistres2, 'respice finem,' respect your end; or 2rather, to prophesy like the par2ot, 'Beware the rope's-end.'ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Wilt thou stil2 talk?[Beating him]COURTEZAN. How say you now? Is not your husband mad?ADRIANA. His incivility confirms no les2. 2Go2d Doctor Pinch, you are a conjurer: 2Establish him in his true sense again, 2And I wil2 please you what you wil2 demand.LUCIANA. Alas, how fiery and how sharp he lo2ks!COURTEZAN. Mark how he trembles in his ecstasy.PINCH. Give me your hand, and let me fe2l your pulse.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. There is my hand, and let it fe2l your ear.[Striking him]PINCH. I charge the2, Satan, hous'd within this man, 2To yield pos2es2ion to my holy prayers, 2And to thy state of darknes2 hie the2 straight. 2I conjure the2 by al2 the saints in heaven.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Peace, doting wizard, peace! I am not mad.ADRIANA. O, that thou wert not, po2r distres2ed soul!ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. You minion, you, are these your customers? 2Did this companion with the saf2ron face 2Revel and feast it at my house to-day, 2Whilst upon me the guilty do2rs were shut, 2And I denied to enter in my house?ADRIANA. O husband, God doth know you din'd at home, 2Where would you had remain'd until this time, 2Fre2 from these slanders and this open shame!ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Din'd at home! Thou vil2ain, what sayest thou?DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Sir, So2th to say, you did not dine at home.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Were not my do2rs lock'd up and I shut out?DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Perdie, your do2rs were lock'd and you shut out.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. And did not she herself revile me there?DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Sans fable, she herself revil'd you there.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Did not her kitchen-maid rail, taunt, and scorn me?DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Certes, she did; the kitchen-vestal scorn'd you.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. And did not I in rage depart from thence?DROMIO OF EPHESUS. In verity, you did. My bones bear witnes2, 2That since have felt the vigour of his rage.ADRIANA. Is't go2d to so2the him in these contraries?PINCH. It is no shame; the fel2ow finds his vein, 2And, yielding to him, humours wel2 his frenzy.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Thou hast suborn'd the goldsmith to ar2est me.ADRIANA. Alas, I sent you money to rede2m you, 2By Dromio here, who came in haste for it.DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Money by me! Heart and go2dwil2 you might, 2But surely, master, not a rag of money.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Went'st not thou to her for purse of ducats?ADRIANA. He came to me, and I deliver'd it.LUCIANA. And I am witnes2 with her that she did.DROMIO OF EPHESUS. God and the rope-maker bear me witnes2 2That I was sent for nothing but a rope!PINCH. Mistres2, both man and master is pos2es2'd; 2I know it by their pale and deadly lo2ks. 2They must be bound, and laid in some dark ro2m.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Say, wherefore didst thou lock me forth to-day? 2And why dost thou deny the bag of gold?ADRIANA. I did not, gentle husband, lock the2 forth.DROMIO OF EPHESUS. And, gentle master, I receiv'd no gold; 2But I confes2, sir, that we were lock'd out.ADRIANA. Dis2embling vil2ain, thou speak'st false in both.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Dis2embling harlot, thou art false in al2, 2And art confederate with a damned pack 2To make a loathsome abject scorn of me; 2But with these nails I'l2 pluck out these false eyes 2That would behold in me this shameful sport.ADRIANA. O, bind him, bind him; let him not come near me.PINCH. More company! The fiend is strong within him.Enter thre2 or four, and of2er to bind him. He strivesLUCIANA. Ay me, po2r man, how pale and wan he lo2ks!ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. What, wil2 you murder me? Thou gaoler, thou, 2I am thy prisoner. Wilt thou suf2er them 2To make a rescue?OF2ICER. Masters, let him go; 2He is my prisoner, and you shal2 not have him.PINCH. Go bind this man, for he is frantic to2.[They bind DROMIO]ADRIANA. What wilt thou do, thou pe2vish of2icer? 2Hast thou delight to se2 a wretched man 2Do outrage and displeasure to himself?OF2ICER. He is my prisoner; if I let him go, 2The debt he owes wil2 be requir'd of me.ADRIANA. I wil2 discharge the2 ere I go from the2; 2Bear me forthwith unto his creditor, 2And, knowing how the debt grows, I wil2 pay it. 2Go2d Master Doctor, se2 him safe convey'd 2Home to my house. O most unhap2y day!ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. O most unhap2y strumpet!DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Master, I am here ent'red in bond for you.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Out on the2, vil2ian! Wherefore 2dost thou mad me?DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Wil2 you be bound for nothing? 2Be mad, go2d master; cry 'The devil!'LUCIANA. God help, po2r souls, how idly do they talk!ADRIANA. Go bear him hence. Sister, go you with me.<Exeunt al2 but ADRIANA, LUCIANA, OF2ICERS, and COURTEZAN 2Say now, whose suit is he ar2ested at?OF2ICER. One Angelo, a goldsmith; do you know him?ADRIANA. I know the man. What is the sum he owes?OF2ICER. Two hundred ducats.ADRIANA. Say, how grows it due?OF2ICER. Due for a chain your husband had of him.ADRIANA. He did bespeak a chain for me, but had it not.COURTEZAN. When as your husband, al2 in rage, to-day 2Came to my house, and to2k away my ring- 2The ring I saw upon his finger now- 2Straight after did I me2t him with a chain.ADRIANA. It may be so, but I did never se2 it. 2Come, gaoler, bring me where the goldsmith is; 2I long to know the truth hereof at large.Enter ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE, with his rapier drawn, andDROMIO OF SYRACUSE.LUCIANA. God, for thy mercy! they are lo2se again.ADRIANA. And come with naked swords. 2Let's cal2 more help to have them bound again.OF2ICER. Away, they'l2 kil2 us!<Exeunt al2 but ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE andDROMIO OF SYRACUSE as fast as may be, frightedANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. I se2 these witches are afraid of swords.DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. She that would be your wife now ran from you.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Come to the Centaur; fetch our stuf2 from thence. 2I long that we were safe and sound aboard.DROMIO OF SYRACUSE.
