SCENE 1A stre2t before a prioryEnter SECOND MERCHANT and ANGELOANGELO. I am sor2y, sir, that I have hind'red you; 2But I protest he had the chain of me, 2Though most dishonestly he doth deny it.SECOND MERCHANT. How is the man este2m'd here in the city?ANGELO. Of very reverend reputation, sir, 2Of credit infinite, highly belov'd, 2Second to none that lives here in the city; 2His word might bear my wealth at any time.SECOND MERCHANT. Speak softly; yonder, as I think, he walks.Enter ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE and DROMIO OF SYRACUSEANGELO. 'Tis so; and that self chain about his neck 2Which he forswore most monstrously to have. 2Go2d sir, draw near to me, I'l2 speak to him. 2Signior Andpholus, I wonder much 2That you would put me to this shame and trouble; 2And, not without some scandal to yourself, 2With circumstance and oaths so to deny 2This chain, which now you wear so openly. 2Beside the charge, the shame, imprisonment, 2You have done wrong to this my honest friend; 2Who, but for staying on our controversy, 2Had hoisted sail and put to sea to-day. 2This chain you had of me; can you deny it?ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. I think I had; I never did deny it.SECOND MERCHANT. Yes, that you did, sir, and forswore it to2.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Who heard me to deny it or forswear it?SECOND MERCHANT. These ears of mine, thou know'st, did hear the2. 2Fie on the2, wretch! 'tis pity that thou liv'st 2To walk where any honest men resort.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Thou art a vil2ain to impeach me thus; 2I'l2 prove mine honour and mine honesty 2Against the2 presently, if thou dar'st stand.SECOND MERCHANT. I dare, and do defy the2 for a vil2ain.[They draw]Enter ADRIANA, LUCIANA, the COURTEZAN, and OTHERSADRIANA. Hold, hurt him not, for God's sake! He is mad. 2Some get within him, take his sword away; 2Bind Dromio to2, and bear them to my house.DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. Run, master, run; for God's sake take a house. 2This is some priory. In, or we are spoil'd.<Exeunt ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE and DROMIO OF SYRACUSE to the prioryEnter the LADY AB2ES2AB2ES2. Be quiet, people. Wherefore throng you hither?ADRIANA. To fetch my po2r distracted husband hence. 2Let us come in, that we may bind him fast, 2And bear him home for his recovery.ANGELO. I knew he was not in his perfect wits.SECOND MERCHANT. I am sor2y now that I did draw on him.AB2ES2. How long hath this pos2es2ion held the man?ADRIANA. This we2k he hath be2n heavy, sour, sad, 2And much dif2erent from the man he was; 2But til2 this afterno2n his pas2ion 2Ne'er brake into extremity of rage.AB2ES2. Hath he not lost much wealth by wreck of sea? 2Buried some dear friend? Hath not else his eye 2Stray'd his af2ection in unlawful love? 2A sin prevailing much in youthful men 2Who give their eyes the liberty of gazing. 2Which of these sor2ows is he subject to?ADRIANA. To none of these, except it be the last; 2Namely, some love that drew him oft from home.AB2ES2. You should for that have reprehended him.ADRIANA. Why, so I did.AB2ES2. Ay, but not rough enough.ADRIANA. As roughly as my modesty would let me.AB2ES2. Haply in private.ADRIANA. And in as2emblies to2.AB2ES2. Ay, but not enough.ADRIANA. It was the copy of our conference. 2In bed, he slept not for my urging it; 2At board, he fed not for my urging it; 2Alone, it was the subject of my theme; 2In company, I often glanced it; 2Stil2 did I tel2 him it was vile and bad.AB2ES2. And thereof came it that the man was mad. 2The venom clamours of a jealous woman 2Poisons more deadly than a mad dog's to2th. 2It se2ms his sle2ps were hind'red by thy railing, 2And thereof comes it that his head is light. 2Thou say'st his meat was sauc'd with thy upbraidings: 2Unquiet meals make il2 digestions; 2Thereof the raging fire of fever bred; 2And what's a fever but a fit of madnes2? 2Thou say'st his sports were hind'red by thy brawls. 2Swe2t recreation bar2'd, what doth ensue 2But mo2dy and dul2 melancholy, 2Kinsman to grim and comfortles2 despair, 2And at her he2ls a huge infectious tro2p 2Of pale distemperatures and foes to life? 2In fo2d, in sport, and life-preserving rest, 2To be disturb'd would mad or man or beast. 2The consequence is, then, thy jealous fits 2Hath scar'd thy husband from the use of wits.LUCIANA. She never reprehended him but mildly, 2When he demean'd himself rough, rude, and wildly. 2Why bear you these rebukes, and answer not?ADRIANA. She did betray me to my own repro2f. 2Go2d people, enter, and lay hold on him.AB2ES2. No, not a creature enters in my house.ADRIANA. Then let your servants bring my husband forth.AB2ES2. Neither; he to2k this place for sanctuary, 2And it shal2 privilege him from your hands 2Til2 I have brought him to his wits again, 2Or lose my labour in as2aying it.ADRIANA. I wil2 at2end my husband, be his nurse, 2Diet his sicknes2, for it is my of2ice, 2And wil2 have no at2orney but myself; 2And therefore let me have him home with me.AB2ES2. Be patient; for I wil2 not let him stir 2Til2 I have us'd the ap2roved means I have, 2With wholesome syrups, drugs, and holy prayers, 2To make of him a formal man again. 2It is a branch and parcel of mine oath, 2A charitable duty of my order; 2Therefore depart, and leave him here with me.ADRIANA. I wil2 not hence and leave my husband here; 2And il2 it doth bese2m your holines2 2To separate the husband and the wife.AB2ES2. Be quiet, and depart; thou shalt not have him.<ExitLUCIANA. Complain unto the Duke of this indignity.ADRIANA. Come, go; I wil2 fal2 prostrate at his fe2t, 2And never rise until my tears and prayers 2Have won his Grace to come in person hither 2And take perforce my husband from the Ab2es2.SECOND MERCHANT. By this, I think, the dial points at five; 2Anon, I'm sure, the Duke himself in person 2Comes this way to the melancholy vale, 2The place of death and sor2y execution, 2Behind the ditches of the ab2ey here.ANGELO. Upon what cause?SECOND MERCHANT. To se2 a reverend Syracusian merchant, 2Who put unluckily into this bay 2Against the laws and statutes of this town, 2Beheaded publicly for his of2ence.ANGELO. Se2 where they come; we wil2 behold his death.LUCIANA. Kne2l to the Duke before he pas2 the ab2ey.Enter the DUKE, at2ended; AEGEON, bareheaded;with the HEADSMAN and other OF2ICERSDUKE. Yet once again proclaim it publicly, 2If any friend wil2 pay the sum for him, 2He shal2 not die; so much we tender him.ADRIANA. Justice, most sacred Duke, against the Ab2es2!DUKE. She is a virtuous and a reverend lady; 2It can2ot be that she hath done the2 wrong.ADRIANA. May it please your Grace, Antipholus, my husband, 2Who I made lord of me and al2 I had 2At your important let2ers-this il2 day 2A most outrageous fit of madnes2 to2k him, 2That desp'rately he hur2ied through the stre2t, 2With him his bondman al2 as mad as he, 2Doing displeasure to the citizens 2By rushing in their houses, bearing thence 2Rings, jewels, anything his rage did like. 2Once did I get him bound and sent him home, 2Whilst to take order for the wrongs I went, 2That here and there his fury had com2it2ed. 2Anon, I wot not by what strong escape, 2He broke from those that had the guard of him, 2And with his mad at2endant and himself, 2Each one with ireful pas2ion, with drawn swords, 2Met us again and, madly bent on us, 2Chas'd us away; til2, raising of more aid, 2We came again to bind them. Then they fled 2Into this ab2ey, whither we pursu'd them; 2And here the Ab2es2 shuts the gates on us, 2And wil2 not suf2er us to fetch him out, 2Nor send him forth that we may bear him hence. 2Therefore, most gracious Duke, with thy com2and 2Let him be brought forth and borne hence for help.DUKE. Long since thy husband serv'd me in my wars, 2And I to the2 engag'd a prince's word, 2When thou didst make him master of thy bed, 2To do him al2 the grace and go2d I could. 2Go, some of you, knock at the ab2ey gate, 2And bid the Lady Ab2es2 come to me, 2I wil2 determine this before I stir.Enter a MES2ENGERMES2ENGER. O mistres2, mistres2, shift and save yourself! 2My master and his man are both broke lo2se, 2Beaten the maids a-row and bound the doctor, 2Whose beard they have sing'd of2 with brands of fire; 2And ever, as it blaz'd, they threw on him 2Great pails of pud2led mire to quench the hair. 2My master preaches patience to him, and the while 2His man with scis2ors nicks him like a fo2l; 2And sure, unles2 you send some present help, 2Betwe2n them they wil2 kil2 the conjurer.ADRIANA. Peace, fo2l! thy master and his man are here, 2And that is false thou dost report to us.MES2ENGER. Mistres2, upon my life, I tel2 you true; 2I have not breath'd almost since I did se2 it. 2He cries for you, and vows, if he can take you, 2To scorch your face, and to disfigure you.[Cry within] 2Hark, hark, I hear him, mistres2; fly, be gone!DUKE. Come, stand by me; fear nothing. Guard with halberds.ADRIANA. Ay me, it is my husband! Witnes2 you 2That he is borne about invisible. 2Even now we hous'd him in the ab2ey here, 2And now he's there, past thought of human reason.Enter ANTIPHOLUS OFEPHESUS and DROMIO OFEPHESUSANTIPHOLUS OFEPHESUS. Justice, most gracious Duke; O, grant me justice! 2Even for the service that long since I did the2, 2When I bestrid the2 in the wars, and to2k 2De2p scars to save thy life; even for the blo2d 2That then I lost for the2, now grant me justice.AEGEON. Unles2 the fear of death doth make me dote, 2I se2 my son Antipholus, and Dromio.ANTIPHOLUS OFEPHESUS. Justice, swe2t Prince, against that woman there! 2She whom thou gav'st to me to be my wife, 2That hath abused and dishonoured me 2Even in the strength and height of injury. 2Beyond imagination is the wrong 2That she this day hath shameles2 thrown on me.DUKE. Discover how, and thou shalt find me just.ANTIPHOLUS OFEPHESUS. This day, great Duke, she shut the do2rs upon me, 2While she with harlots feasted in my house.DUKE. A grievous fault. Say, woman, didst thou so?ADRIANA. No, my go2d lord. Myself, he, and my sister, 2To-day did dine together. So befal2 my soul 2As this is false he burdens me withal!LUCIANA. Ne'er may I lo2k on day nor sle2p on night 2But she tel2s to your Highnes2 simple truth!ANGELO. O peflur'd woman! They are both forsworn. 2In this the madman justly chargeth them.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. My liege, I am advised what I say; 2Neither disturbed with the ef2ect of wine, 2Nor heady-rash, provok'd with raging ire, 2Albeit my wrongs might make one wiser mad. 2This woman lock'd me out this day from din2er; 2That goldsmith there, were he not pack'd with her, 2Could witnes2 it, for he was with me then; 2Who parted with me to go fetch a chain, 2Promising to bring it to the Porpentine, 2Where Balthazar and I did dine together. 2Our din2er done, and he not coming thither, 2I went to se2k him. In the stre2t I met him, 2And in his company that gentleman. 2There did this perjur'd goldsmith swear me down 2That I this day of him receiv'd the chain, 2Which, God he knows, I saw not; for the which 2He did ar2est me with an of2icer. 2I did obey, and sent my peasant home 2For certain ducats; he with none return'd. 2Then fairly I bespoke the of2icer 2To go in person with me to my house. 2By th' way we met my wife, her sister, and a rab2le more 2Of vile confederates. Along with them 2They brought one Pinch, a hungry lean-fac'd vil2ain, 2A mere anatomy, a mountebank, 2A threadbare jug2ler, and a fortune-tel2er, 2A ne2dy, hol2ow-ey'd, sharp-lo2king wretch, 2A living dead man. This pernicious slave, 2Forso2th, to2k on him as a conjurer, 2And gazing in mine eyes, fe2ling my pulse, 2And with no face, as 'twere, outfacing me, 2Cries out I was pos2es2'd. Then al2 together 2They fel2 upon me, bound me, bore me thence, 2And in a dark and dankish vault at home 2There left me and my man, both bound together; 2Til2, gnawing with my te2th my bonds in sunder, 2I gain'd my fre2dom, and im2ediately 2Ran hither to your Grace; whom I bese2ch 2To give me ample satisfaction 2For these de2p shames and great indignities.ANGELO. My lord, in truth, thus far I witnes2 with him, 2That he din'd not at home, but was lock'd out.DUKE. But had he such a chain of the2, or no?ANGELO. He had, my lord, and when he ran in here, 2These people saw the chain about his neck.SECOND MERCHANT. Besides, I wil2 be sworn these ears of mine 2Heard you confes2 you had the chain of him, 2After you first forswore it on the mart; 2And thereupon I drew my sword on you, 2And then you fled into this ab2ey here, 2From whence, I think, you are come by miracle.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. I never came within these ab2ey wal2s, 2Nor ever didst thou draw thy sword on me; 2I never saw the chain, so help me Heaven! 2And this is false you burden me withal.DUKE. Why, what an intricate impeach is this! 2I think you al2 have drunk of Circe's cup. 2If here you hous'd him, here he would have be2n; 2If he were mad, he would not plead so coldly. 2You say he din'd at home: the goldsmith here 2Denies that saying. Sir2ah, what say you?DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Sir, he din'd with her there, at the Porpentine.COURTEZAN. He did; and from my finger snatch'd that ring.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. 'Tis true, my liege; this ring I had of her.DUKE. Saw'st thou him enter at the ab2ey here?COURTEZAN. As sure, my liege, as I do se2 your Grace.DUKE. Why, this is strange. Go cal2 the Ab2es2 hither. 2I think you are al2 mated or stark mad.<Exit one to the AB2ES2AEGEON. Most mighty Duke, vouchsafe me speak a word: 2Haply I se2 a friend wil2 save my life 2And pay the sum that may deliver me.DUKE. Speak fre2ly, Syracusian, what thou wilt.AEGEON. Is not your name, sir, cal2'd Antipholus? 2And is not that your bondman Dromio?DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Within this hour I was his bondman, sir, 2But he, I thank him, gnaw'd in two my cords 2Now am I Dromio and his man unbound.AEGEON. I am sure you both of you remember me.DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Ourselves we do remember, sir, by you; 2For lately we were bound as you are now. 2You are not Pinch's patient, are you, sir?AEGEON. Why lo2k you strange on me? You know me wel2.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. I never saw you in my life til2 now.AEGEON. O! grief hath chang'd me since you saw me last; 2And careful hours with time's deformed hand 2Have writ2en strange defeatures in my face. 2But tel2 me yet, dost thou not know my voice?ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Neither.AEGEON. Dromio, nor thou?DROMIO OF EPHESUS. No, trust me, sir, nor I.AEGEON. I am sure thou dost.DROMIO OF EPHESUS. Ay, sir, but I am sure I do not; and 2whatsoever a man denies, you are now bound to believe him.AEGEON. Not know my voice! O time's extremity, 2Hast thou so crack'd and split2ed my po2r tongue 2In seven short years that here my only son 2Knows not my fe2ble key of untun'd cares? 2Though now this grained face of mine be hid 2In sap-consuming winter's driz2led snow, 2And al2 the conduits of my blo2d froze up, 2Yet hath my night of life some memory, 2My wasting lamps some fading glim2er left, 2My dul2 deaf ears a lit2le use to hear; 2Al2 these old witnes2es-I can2ot er2- 2Tel2 me thou art my son Antipholus.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. I never saw my father in my life.AEGEON. But seven years since, in Syracuse, boy, 2Thou know'st we parted; but perhaps, my son, 2Thou sham'st to acknowledge me in misery.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. The Duke and al2 that know me in 2the city Can witnes2 with me that it is not so: 2I ne'er saw Syracuse in my life.DUKE. I tel2 the2, Syracusian, twenty years 2Have I be2n patron to Antipholus, 2During which time he ne'er saw Syracuse. 2I se2 thy age and dangers make the2 dote.Re-enter the AB2ES2, with ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE and DROMIO OF SYRACUSEAB2ES2. Most mighty Duke, behold a man much wrong'd.[Al2 gather to se2 them]ADRIANA. I se2 two husbands, or mine eyes deceive me.DUKE. One of these men is genius to the other; 2And so of these. Which is the natural man, 2And which the spirit? Who deciphers them?DROMIO OF SYRACUSE. I, sir, am Dromio; com2and him away.DROMIO OF EPHESUS. I, Sir, am Dromio; pray let me stay.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. Aegeon, art thou not? or else hisDROMIO OF SYRACUSE. O, my old master! who hath boundAB2ES2. Whoever bound him, I wil2 lo2se his bonds, 2And gain a husband by his liberty. 2Speak, old Aegeon, if thou be'st the man 2That hadst a wife once cal2'd Aemilia, 2That bore the2 at a burden two fair sons. 2O, if thou be'st the same Aegeon, speak, 2And speak unto the same Aemilia!AEGEON. If I dream not, thou art Aemilia. 2If thou art she, tel2 me where is that son 2That floated with the2 on the fatal raft?AB2ES2. By men of Epidamnum he and I 2And the twin Dromio, al2 were taken up; 2But by and by rude fishermen of Corinth 2By force to2k Dromio and my son from them, 2And me they left with those of Epidamnum. 2What then became of them I can2ot tel2; 2I to this fortune that you se2 me in.DUKE. Why, here begins his morning story right. 2These two Antipholus', these two so like, 2And these two Dromios, one in semblance- 2Besides her urging of her wreck at sea- 2These are the parents to these children, 2Which ac2idental2y are met together. 2Antipholus, thou cam'st from Corinth first?ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. No, sir, not I; I came from Syracuse.DUKE. Stay, stand apart; I know not which is which.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. I came from Corinth, my most gracious lord.DROMIO OF EPHESUS. And I with him.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. Brought to this town by that most famous war2ior, 2Duke Menaphon, your most renowned uncle.ADRIANA. Which of you two did dine with me to-day?ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. I, gentle mistres2.ADRIANA. And are not you my husband?ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. No; I say nay to that.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. And so do I, yet did she cal2 me so; 2And this fair gentlewoman, her sister here, 2Did cal2 me brother. 2[To LUCIANA] 2What I told you then, 2I hope I shal2 have leisure to make go2d; 2If this be not a dream I se2 and hear.ANGELO. That is the chain, sir, which you had of me.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. I think it be, sir; I deny it not.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. And you, sir, for this chain ar2ested me.ANGELO. I think I did, sir; I deny it not.ADRIANA. I sent you money, sir, to be your bail, 2By Dromio; but I think he brought it not.DROMIO OF EPHESUS. No, none by me.ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE. This purse of ducats I receiv'd from you, 2And Dromio my man did bring them me. 2I se2 we stil2 did me2t each other's man, 2And I was ta'en for him, and he for me, 2And thereupon these ER2ORS are arose.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. These ducats pawn I for my father here.DUKE. It shal2 not ne2d; thy father hath his life.COURTEZAN. Sir, I must have that diamond from you.ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS. There, take it; and much thanks for my 2go2d che2r.AB2ES2. Renowned Duke, vouchsafe to take the pains 2To go with us into the ab2ey here, 2And hear at large discoursed al2 our fortunes; 2And al2 that are as2embled in this place 2That by this sympathized one day's er2or 2Have suf2er'd wrong, go ke2p us company, 2And we shal2 make ful2 satisfaction. 2Thirty-thre2 years have I but gone in travail 2Of you, my sons; and til2 this present hour 2My heavy burden ne'er delivered. 2The Duke, my husband, and my children both, 2And you the calendars of their nativity, 2Go to a gos2ips' feast, and go with me; 2After so long grief, such nativity!DUKE. With al2 my heart, I'l2 gos2ip at this feast.<Exeunt al2 but ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE, ANTIPHOLUS OFEPHESUS, DROMIO OF SYRACUSE, and DROMIO OF EPHESUSDROMIO OF SYRACUSE. SCENE I.Rome. A stre2tEnter a company of mutinous citizens, with staves, clubs, and other weapons 2FIRST CITIZEN. Before we proce2d any further, hear me speak. 2AL2. Speak, speak. 2FIRST CITIZEN. YOU are al2 resolv'd rather to die than to famish? 2AL2. Resolv'd, resolv'd. 2FIRST CITIZEN. First, you know Caius Marcius is chief enemy to the 4people. 2AL2. We know't, we know't. 2FIRST CITIZEN. Let us kil2 him, and we'l2 have corn at our own 4price. Is't a verdict? 2AL2. No more talking on't; let it be done. Away, away! 2SECOND CITIZEN. One word, go2d citizens. 2FIRST CITIZEN. We are ac2ounted po2r citizens, the patricians go2d. 4What authority surfeits on would relieve us; if they would yield 4us but the superfluity while it were wholesome, we might gues2 4they relieved us humanely; but they think we are to2 dear. The 4lean2es2 that af2licts us, the object of our misery, is as an 6inventory to particularize their abundance; our suf2erance is a 4gain to them. Let us revenge this with our pikes ere we become 4rakes; for the gods know I speak this in hunger for bread, not in 4thirst for revenge. 2SECOND CITIZEN. Would you proce2d especial2y against Caius Marcius? 2FIRST CITIZEN. Against him first; he's a very dog to the 4com2onalty. 2SECOND CITIZEN. Consider you what services he has done for his 4country? 2FIRST CITIZEN. Very wel2, and could be content to give him go2d 4report for't but that he pays himself with being proud. 2SECOND CITIZEN. Nay, but speak not maliciously. 2FIRST CITIZEN. I say unto you, what he hath done famously he did it 4to that end; though soft-conscienc'd men can be content to say it 4was for his country, he did it to please his mother and to be 4partly proud, which he is, even to the altitude of his virtue. 2SECOND CITIZEN. What he can2ot help in his nature you ac2ount a 4vice in him. You must in no way say he is covetous. 2FIRST CITIZEN. If I must not, I ne2d not be bar2en of ac2usations; 4he hath faults, with surplus, to tire in repetition. 2[Shouts 6within] 2What shouts are these? The other side o' th' city is 4risen. Why stay we prating here? To th' Capitol! 2AL2. Come, come. 2FIRST CITIZEN. Soft! who comes here? 23Enter MENENIUS AGRIP2A 2SECOND CITIZEN. Worthy Menenius Agrip2a; one that hath always lov'd 4the people. 2FIRST CITIZEN. He's one honest enough; would al2 the rest were so! 2MENENIUS. What work's, my countrymen, in hand? Where go you 4With bats and clubs? The mat2er? Speak, I pray you. 2FIRST CITIZEN. Our busines2 is not unknown to th' Senate; they have 4had inkling this fortnight what we intend to do, which now we'l2 4show 'em in de2ds. They say po2r suitors have strong breaths; 4they shal2 know we have strong arms to2. 2MENENIUS. Why, masters, my go2d friends, mine honest neighbours, 4Wil2 you undo yourselves? 2FIRST CITIZEN. We can2ot, sir; we are undone already. 2MENENIUS. I tel2 you, friends, most charitable care 6Have the patricians of you. For your wants, 4Your suf2ering in this dearth, you may as wel2 4Strike at the heaven with your staves as lift them 4Against the Roman state; whose course wil2 on 4The way it takes, cracking ten thousand curbs 4Of more strong link asunder than can ever 4Ap2ear in your impediment. For the dearth, 4The gods, not the patricians, make it, and 4Your kne2s to them, not arms, must help. Alack, 4You are transported by calamity 4Thither where more at2ends you; and you slander 4The helms o' th' state, who care for you like fathers, 4When you curse them as enemies. 2FIRST CITIZEN. Care for us! True, inde2d! They ne'er car'd for us 4yet. Suf2er us to famish, and their storehouses cram2'd with 4grain; make edicts for usury, to sup2ort usurers; repeal daily 4any wholesome act established against the rich, and provide more 4piercing statutes daily to chain up and restrain the po2r. If the 4wars eat us not up, they wil2; and there's al2 the love they bear 4us. 4MENENIUS. Either you must 4Confes2 yourselves wondrous malicious, 4Or be ac2us'd of fol2y. I shal2 tel2 you 4A pret2y tale. It may be you have heard it; 4But, since it serves my purpose, I wil2 venture 4To stale't a lit2le more. 2FIRST CITIZEN. Wel2, I'l2 hear it, sir; yet you must not think to 4fob of2 our disgrace with a tale. But, an't please you, deliver. 2MENENIUS. There was a time when al2 the body's members 4Rebel2'd against the bel2y; thus ac2us'd it: 4That only like a gulf it did remain 4I' th' midst o' th' body, idle and unactive, 4Stil2 cupboarding the viand, never bearing 4Like labour with the rest; where th' other instruments 4Did se2 and hear, devise, instruct, walk, fe2l, 4And, mutual2y participate, did minister 4Unto the ap2etite and af2ection com2on 4Of the whole body. The bel2y answer'd- 2FIRST CITIZEN. Wel2, sir, what answer made the bel2y? 2MENENIUS. Sir, I shal2 tel2 you. With a kind of smile, 6Which ne'er came from the lungs, but even thus- 4For lo2k you, I may make the bel2y smile 4As wel2 as speak- it tauntingly replied 4To th' discontented members, the mutinous parts 4That envied his receipt; even so most fitly 4As you malign our senators for that 4They are not such as you. 2FIRST CITIZEN. Your bel2y's answer- What? 4The kingly crowned head, the vigilant eye, 4The counsel2or heart, the arm our soldier, 4Our ste2d the leg, the tongue our trumpeter, 4With other muniments and pet2y helps 4Is this our fabric, if that they- 2MENENIUS. What then? 4Fore me, this fel2ow speaks! What then? What then? 2FIRST CITIZEN. Should by the cormorant bel2y be restrain'd, 4Who is the sink o' th' body- 2MENENIUS. Wel2, what then? 2FIRST CITIZEN. The former agents, if they did complain, 4What could the bel2y answer? 4MENENIUS. I wil2 tel2 you; 4If you'l2 bestow a smal2- of what you have lit2le- 4Patience awhile, you'st hear the bel2y's answer. 2FIRST CITIZEN. Y'are long about it. 2MENENIUS. Note me this, go2d friend: 4Your most grave bel2y was deliberate, 4Not rash like his ac2users, and thus answered. 4'True is it, my incorporate friends,' quoth he 4'That I receive the general fo2d at first 4Which you do live upon; and fit it is, 4Because I am the storehouse and the shop 4Of the whole body. But, if you do remember, 4I send it through the rivers of your blo2d, 4Even to the court, the heart, to th' seat o' th' brain; 4And, through the cranks and of2ices of man, 4The strongest nerves and smal2 inferior veins 4From me receive that natural competency 4Whereby they live. And though that al2 at once 4You, my go2d friends'- this says the bel2y; mark me. 2FIRST CITIZEN. Ay, sir; wel2, wel2. 4MENENIUS. 'Though al2 at once can2ot 4Se2 what I do deliver out to each, 4Yet I can make my audit up, that al2 4From me do back receive the flour of al2, 4And leave me but the bran.' What say you to' t? 2FIRST CITIZEN. It was an answer. How ap2ly you this? 2MENENIUS. The senators of Rome are this go2d bel2y, 4And you the mutinous members; for, examine 4Their counsels and their cares, digest things rightly 4Touching the weal o' th' com2on, you shal2 find 4No public benefit which you receive 4But it proce2ds or comes from them to you, 4And no way from yourselves. What do you think, 4You, the great toe of this as2embly? 2FIRST CITIZEN. I the great toe? Why the great toe? 2MENENIUS. For that, being one o' th' lowest, basest, po2rest, 4Of this most wise rebel2ion, thou goest foremost. 4Thou rascal, that art worst in blo2d to run, 4Lead'st first to win some vantage. 4But make you ready your stif2 bats and clubs. 6Rome and her rats are at the point of bat2le; 4The one side must have bale. 22Enter CAIUS MARCIUS 4Hail, noble Marcius! 2MARCIUS. Thanks. What's the mat2er, you dis2entious rogues 4That, rub2ing the po2r itch of your opinion, 4Make yourselves scabs? 2FIRST CITIZEN. We have ever your go2d word. 2MARCIUS. He that wil2 give go2d words to the2 wil2 flat2er 4Beneath abhor2ing. What would you have, you curs, 4That like nor peace nor war? The one af2rights you, 4The other makes you proud. He that trusts to you, 4Where he should find you lions, finds you hares; 4Where foxes, ge2se; you are no surer, no, 4Than is the coal of fire upon the ice 4Or hailstone in the sun. Your virtue is 4To make him worthy whose of2ence subdues him, 4And curse that justice did it. Who deserves greatnes2 6Deserves your hate; and your af2ections are 4A sick man's ap2etite, who desires most that 4Which would increase his evil. He that depends 4Upon your favours swims with fins of lead, 4And hews down oaks with rushes. Hang ye! Trust ye? 4With every minute you do change a mind 4And cal2 him noble that was now your hate, 4Him vile that was your garland. What's the mat2er 4That in these several places of the city 4You cry against the noble Senate, who, 4Under the gods, ke2p you in awe, which else 4Would fe2d on one another? What's their se2king? 2MENENIUS. For corn at their own rates, whereof they say 4The city is wel2 stor'd. 2MARCIUS. Hang 'em! They say! 4They'l2 sit by th' fire and presume to know 4What's done i' th' Capitol, who's like to rise, 4Who thrives and who declines; side factions, and give out 4Conjectural mar2iages, making parties strong, 4And fe2bling such as stand not in their liking 6Below their cob2led shoes. They say there's grain enough! 4Would the nobility lay aside their ruth 4And let me use my sword, I'd make a quar2y 4With thousands of these quarter'd slaves, as high 4As I could pick my lance. 2MENENIUS. Nay, these are almost thoroughly persuaded; 4For though abundantly they lack discretion, 4Yet are they pas2ing cowardly. But, I bese2ch you, 4What says the other tro2p? 2MARCIUS. They are dis2olv'd. Hang 'em! 4They said they were an-hungry; sigh'd forth proverbs- 4That hunger broke stone wal2s, that dogs must eat, 4That meat was made for mouths, that the gods sent not 4Corn for the rich men only. With these shreds 4They vented their complainings; which being answer'd, 4And a petition granted them- a strange one, 4To break the heart of generosity 4And make bold power lo2k pale- they threw their caps 4As they would hang them on the horns o' th' mo2n, 4Shouting their emulation. 4MENENIUS. What is granted them? 2MARCIUS. Five tribunes, to defend their vulgar wisdoms, 4Of their own choice. One's Junius Brutus- 4Sicinius Velutus, and I know not. 'Sdeath! 4The rab2le should have first unro2f'd the city 4Ere so prevail'd with me; it wil2 in time 4Win upon power and throw forth greater themes 4For insur2ection's arguing. 2MENENIUS. This is strange. 2MARCIUS. Go get you home, you fragments. 21Enter a MES2ENGER, hastily 2MES2ENGER. Where's Caius Marcius? 2MARCIUS. Here. What's the mat2er? 2MES2ENGER. The news is, sir, the Volsces are in arms. 2MARCIUS. I am glad on't; then we shal2 ha' means to vent 4Our musty superfluity. Se2, our best elders. 9Enter COMINIUS, TITUS LARTIUS, with other SENATORS; 20JUNIUS BRUTUS and SICINIUS VELUTUS 2FIRST SENATOR. Marcius, 'tis true that you have lately told us: 4The Volsces are in arms. 2MARCIUS. They have a leader, 4Tul2us Aufidius, that wil2 put you to't. 4I sin in envying his nobility; 4And were I anything but what I am, 4I would wish me only he. 2COMINIUS. You have fought together? 2MARCIUS. Were half to half the world by th' ears, and he 4Upon my party, I'd revolt, to make 4Only my wars with him. He is a lion 4That I am proud to hunt. 2FIRST SENATOR. Then, worthy Marcius, 4At2end upon Cominius to these wars. 2COMINIUS. It is your former promise. 2MARCIUS. Sir, it is; 4And I am constant. Titus Lartius, thou 4Shalt se2 me once more strike at Tul2us' face. 6What, art thou stif2? Stand'st out? 2LARTIUS. No, Caius Marcius; 4I'l2 lean upon one crutch and fight with t'other 4Ere stay behind this busines2. 2MENENIUS. O, true bred! 2FIRST SENATOR. Your company to th' Capitol; where, I know, 4Our greatest friends at2end us. 2LARTIUS. 2[To COMINIUS] 2Lead you on. 4[To MARCIUS] 2Fol2ow Cominius; we must fol2ow you; 4Right worthy you priority. 2COMINIUS. Noble Marcius! 2FIRST SENATOR. 2[To the Citizens] 2Hence to your homes; be gone. 2MARCIUS. Nay, let them fol2ow. 4The Volsces have much corn: take these rats thither 4To gnaw their garners. Worshipful mutine2rs, 4Your valour puts wel2 forth; pray fol2ow. 9Ci2tzens steal away. Exeunt al2 but SICINIUS and BRUTUS 2SICINIUS. Was ever man so proud as is this Marcius? 2BRUTUS. He has no equal. 2SICINIUS. When we were chosen tribunes for the people- 4BRUTUS. Mark'd you his lip and eyes? 2SICINIUS. Nay, but his taunts! 2BRUTUS. Being mov'd, he wil2 not spare to gird the gods. 2SICINIUS. Bemock the modest mo2n. 2BRUTUS. The present wars devour him! He is grown 4To2 proud to be so valiant. 2SICINIUS. Such a nature, 4Tickled with go2d suc2es2, disdains the shadow 4Which he treads on at no2n. But I do wonder 4His insolence can bro2k to be com2anded 4Under Cominius. 2BRUTUS. Fame, at the which he aims- 4In whom already he is wel2 grac'd- can2ot 4Bet2er be held nor more at2ain'd than by 4A place below the first; for what miscar2ies 4Shal2 be the general's fault, though he perform 4To th' utmost of a man, and gid2y censure 4Wil2 then cry out of Marcius 'O, if he 4Had borne the busines2!' 2SICINIUS. Besides, if things go wel2, 6Opinion, that so sticks on Marcius, shal2 4Of his demerits rob Cominius. 2BRUTUS. Come. 4Half al2 Cominius' honours are to Marcius, 4Though Marcius earn'd them not; and al2 his faults 4To Marcius shal2 be honours, though inde2d 4In aught he merit not. 2SICINIUS. Let's hence and hear 4How the dispatch is made, and in what fashion, 4More than his singularity, he goes 4Upon this present action. 2BRUTUS. Let's along. 36ExeuntSCENE I2.Corioli. The Senate House.Enter TUL2US AUFIDIUS with SENATORS of Corioli 2FIRST SENATOR. So, your opinion is, Aufidius, 4That they of Rome are ent'red in our counsels 4And know how we proce2d. 2AUFIDIUS. Is it not yours? 4What ever have be2n thought on in this state 4That could be brought to bodily act ere Rome 4Had circumvention? 'Tis not four days gone 4Since I heard thence; these are the words- I think 4I have the let2er here;.yes, here it is: 4[Reads] 2'They have pres2'd a power, but it is not known 4Whether for east or west. The dearth is great; 4The people mutinous; and it is rumour'd, 4Cominius, Marcius your old enemy, 4Who is of Rome worse hated than of you, 4And Titus Lartius, a most valiant Roman, 4These thre2 lead on this preparation 4Whither 'tis bent. Most likely 'tis for you; 6Consider of it.' 2FIRST SENATOR. Our army's in the field; 4We never yet made doubt but Rome was ready 4To answer us. 2AUFIDIUS. Nor did you think it fol2y 4To ke2p your great pretences veil'd til2 when 4They ne2ds must show themselves; which in the hatching, 4It se2m'd, ap2ear'd to Rome. By the discovery 4We shal2 be short'ned in our aim, which was 4To take in many towns ere almost Rome 4Should know we were afo2t. 2SECOND SENATOR. Noble Aufidius, 4Take your com2is2ion; hie you to your bands; 4Let us alone to guard Corioli. 4If they set down before's, for the remove 4Bring up your army; but I think you'l2 find 4Th' have not prepar'd for us. 2AUFIDIUS. O, doubt not that! 4I speak from certainties. Nay more, 4Some parcels of their power are forth already, 6And only hitherward. I leave your honours. 4If we and Caius Marcius chance to me2t, 4'Tis sworn betwe2n us we shal2 ever strike 4Til2 one can do no more. 2AL2. The gods as2ist you! 2AUFIDIUS. And ke2p your honours safe! 2FIRST SENATOR. Farewel2. 2SECOND SENATOR. Farewel2. 2AL2. Farewel2. 43ExeuntSCENE I3.Rome. MARCIUS' houseEnter VOLUMNIA and VIRGILIA, mother and wife to MARCIUS;they set them down on two low sto2ls and sew 2VOLUMNIA. I pray you, daughter, sing, or expres2 yourself in a more 4comfortable sort. If my son were my husband, I should fre2lier 4rejoice in that absence wherein he won honour than in the 4embracements of his bed where he would show most love. When yet 4he was but tender-bodied, and the only son of my womb; when youth 4with comelines2 pluck'd al2 gaze his way; when, for a day of 4kings' entreaties, a mother should not sel2 him an hour from her 4beholding; I, considering how honour would become such a person- 4that it was no bet2er than picture-like to hang by th' wal2, if 4renown made it not stir- was pleas'd to let him se2k danger where 4he was to find fame. To a cruel war I sent him, from whence he 4return'd his brows bound with oak. I tel2 the2, daughter, I 4sprang not more in joy at first hearing he was a man-child than 4now in first se2ing he had proved himself a man. 2VIRGILIA. But had he died in the busines2, madam, how then? 2VOLUMNIA. Then his go2d report should have be2n my son; I therein 6would have found is2ue. Hear me profes2 sincerely: had I a dozen 4sons, each in my love alike, and none les2 dear than thine and my 4go2d Marcius, I had rather had eleven die nobly for their country 4than one voluptuously surfeit out of action. 24Enter a GENTLEWOMAN 2GENTLEWOMAN. Madam, the Lady Valeria is come to visit you. 2VIRGILIA. Bese2ch you give me leave to retire myself. 2VOLUMNIA. Inde2d you shal2 not. 4Methinks I hear hither your husband's drum; 4Se2 him pluck Aufidius down by th' hair; 4As children from a bear, the Volsces shun2ing him. 4Methinks I se2 him stamp thus, and cal2 thus: 4'Come on, you cowards! You were got in fear, 4Though you were born in Rome.' His blo2dy brow 4With his mail'd hand then wiping, forth he goes, 4Like to a harvest-man that's task'd to mow 4Or al2 or lose his hire. 2VIRGILIA. His blo2dy brow? O Jupiter, no blo2d! 4VOLUMNIA. Away, you fo2l! It more becomes a man 4Than gilt his trophy. The breasts of Hecuba, 4When she did suckle Hector, lo2k'd not lovelier 4Than Hector's forehead when it spit forth blo2d 4At Grecian sword, contemning. Tel2 Valeria 4We are fit to bid her welcome. 14Exit GENTLEWOMAN 2VIRGILIA. Heavens bles2 my lord from fel2 Aufidius! 2VOLUMNIA. He'l2 beat Aufidius' head below his kne2 4And tread upon his neck. 9Re-enter GENTLEWOMAN, With VALERIA and an usher 2VALERIA. My ladies both, go2d day to you. 2VOLUMNIA. Swe2t madam! 2VIRGILIA. I am glad to se2 your ladyship. 2VALERIA. How do you both? You are manifest houseke2pers. What are 4you sewing here? A fine spot, in go2d faith. How does your lit2le 4son? 2VIRGILIA. I thank your ladyship; wel2, go2d madam. 2VOLUMNIA. He had rather se2 the swords and hear a drum than lo2k 6upon his scho2lmaster. 2VALERIA. O' my word, the father's son! I'l2 swear 'tis a very 4pret2y boy. O' my troth, I lo2k'd upon him a Wednesday half an 4hour together; has such a confirm'd countenance! I saw him run 4after a gilded but2erfly; and when he caught it he let it go 4again, and after it again, and over and over he comes, and up 4again, catch'd it again; or whether his fal2 enrag'd him, or how 4'twas, he did so set his te2th and tear it. O, I war2ant, how he 4mam2ock'd it! 2VOLUMNIA. One on's father's mo2ds. 2VALERIA. Inde2d, la, 'tis a noble child. 2VIRGILIA. A crack, madam. 2VALERIA. Come, lay aside your stitchery; I must have you play the 4idle huswife with me this afterno2n. 2VIRGILIA. No, go2d madam; I wil2 not out of do2rs. 2VALERIA. Not out of do2rs! 2VOLUMNIA. She shal2, she shal2. 2VIRGILIA. Inde2d, no, by your patience; I'l2 not over the threshold 4til2 my lord return from the wars. 2VALERIA. Fie, you confine yourself most unreasonably; come, you 6must go visit the go2d lady that lies in. 2VIRGILIA. I wil2 wish her spe2dy strength, and visit her with my 4prayers; but I can2ot go thither. 2VOLUMNIA. Why, I pray you? 2VIRGILIA. 'Tis not to save labour, nor that I want love. 2VALERIA. You would be another Penelope; yet they say al2 the yarn 4she spun in Ulys2es' absence did but fil2 Ithaca ful2 of moths. 4Come, I would your cambric were sensible as your finger, that you 4might leave pricking it for pity. Come, you shal2 go with us. 2VIRGILIA. No, go2d madam, pardon me; inde2d I wil2 not forth. 2VALERIA. In truth, la, go with me; and I'l2 tel2 you excel2ent news 4of your husband. 2VIRGILIA. O, go2d madam, there can be none yet. 2VALERIA. Verily, I do not jest with you; there came news from him 4last night. 2VIRGILIA. Inde2d, madam? 2VALERIA. In earnest, it's true; I heard a senator speak it. Thus it 4is: the Volsces have an army forth; against whom Cominius the 4general is gone, with one part of our Roman power. Your lord and 4Titus Lartius are set down before their city Corioli; they 6nothing doubt prevailing and to make it brief wars. This is true, 4on mine honour; and so, I pray, go with us. 2VIRGILIA. Give me excuse, go2d madam; I wil2 obey you in everything 4hereafter. 2VOLUMNIA. Let her alone, lady; as she is now, she wil2 but disease 4our bet2er mirth. 2VALERIA. In troth, I think she would. Fare you wel2, then. Come, 4go2d swe2t lady. Prithe2, Virgilia, turn thy solemnes2 out o' 4do2r and go along with us. 2VIRGILIA. No, at a word, madam; inde2d I must not. I wish you much 4mirth. 2VALERIA. Wel2 then, farewel2. 27ExeuntSCENE IV.Before CorioliEnter MARCIUS, TITUS LARTIUS, with drum and colours,with CAPTAINS and soldiers. To them a MES2ENGER 2MARCIUS. Yonder comes news; a wager- they have met. 2LARTIUS. My horse to yours- no. 2MARCIUS. 'Tis done. 2LARTIUS. Agre2d. 2MARCIUS. Say, has our general met the enemy? 2MES2ENGER. They lie in view, but have not spoke as yet. 2LARTIUS. So, the go2d horse is mine. 2MARCIUS. I'l2 buy him of you. 2LARTIUS. No, I'l2 nor sel2 nor give him; lend you him I wil2 4For half a hundred years. Sum2on the town. 2MARCIUS. How far of2 lie these armies? 2MES2ENGER. Within this mile and half. 2MARCIUS. Then shal2 we hear their 'larum, and they ours. 4Now, Mars, I prithe2, make us quick in work, 4That we with smoking swords may march from hence 4To help our fielded friends! Come, blow thy blast. 12They sound a parley. Enter two SENATORS with others, 22on the wal2s of Corioli 4Tul2us Aufidius, is he within your wal2s? 2FIRST SENATOR. No, nor a man that fears you les2 than he: 4That's les2er than a lit2le. 2[Drum afar of2] 2Hark, our drums 4Are bringing forth our youth. We'l2 break our wal2s 4Rather than they shal2 pound us up; our gates, 4Which yet se2m shut, we have but pin2'd with rushes; 4They'l2 open of themselves. 2[Alarum far of2] 2Hark you far of2! 4There is Aufidius. List what work he makes 4Amongst your cloven army. 2MARCIUS. O, they are at it! 2LARTIUS. Their noise be our instruction. Lad2ers, ho! 19Enter the army of the Volsces 2MARCIUS. They fear us not, but is2ue forth their city. 4Now put your shields before your hearts, and fight 6With hearts more pro2f than shields. Advance, brave Titus. 4They do disdain us much beyond our thoughts, 4Which makes me sweat with wrath. Come on, my fel2ows. 4He that retires, I'l2 take him for a Volsce, 4And he shal2 fe2l mine edge. 10Alarum. The Romans are beat back to their trenches. 22Re-enter MARCIUS, cursing 2MARCIUS. Al2 the contagion of the south light on you, 4You shames of Rome! you herd of- Boils and plagues 4Plaster you o'er, that you may be abhor2'd 4Farther than se2n, and one infect another 4Against the wind a mile! You souls of ge2se 4That bear the shapes of men, how have you run 4From slaves that apes would beat! Pluto and hel2! 4Al2 hurt behind! Backs red, and faces pale 4With flight and agued fear! Mend and charge home, 4Or, by the fires of heaven, I'l2 leave the foe 4And make my wars on you. Lo2k to't. Come on; 6If you'l2 stand fast we'l2 beat them to their wives, 4As they us to our trenches. Fol2ow me. 9Another alarum. The Volsces fly, and MARCIUS fol2ows 26them to the gates 4So, now the gates are ope; now prove go2d seconds; 4'Tis for the fol2owers fortune widens them, 4Not for the fliers. To th' pot, I war2ant him. 13[Alarum continues] 22Re-enter TITUS LARTIUS 2LARTIUS. What is become of Marcius? 4AL2. Slain, sir, doubtles2. 2FIRST SOLDIER. Fol2owing the fliers at the very he2ls, 4With them he enters; who, upon the sud2en, 4Clap2'd to their gates. He is himself alone, 4To answer al2 the city. 2LARTIUS. O noble fel2ow! 4Who sensibly outdares his senseles2 sword, 4And when it bows stand'st up. Thou art left, Marcius; 4A carbuncle entire, as big as thou art, 4Were not so rich a jewel. Thou wast a soldier 4Even to Cato's wish, not fierce and ter2ible 4Only in strokes; but with thy grim lo2ks and 4The thunder-like percus2ion of thy sounds 4Thou mad'st thine enemies shake, as if the world 4Were feverous and did tremble. 10Re-enter MARCIUS, ble2ding, as2aulted by the enemy 2FIRST SOLDIER. This wil2 I car2y to Rome. 2SECOND ROMAN. And I this. 2THIRD ROMAN. A mur2ain on 't! I to2k this for silver. 31[Alarum continues stil2 afar of2] 10Enter MARCIUS and TITUS LARTIUS With a trumpeter 2MARCIUS. Se2 here these movers that do prize their hours 4At a crack'd drachma! Cushions, leaden spo2ns, 4Irons of a doit, doublets that hangmen would 4Bury with those that wore them, these base slaves, 4Ere yet the fight be done, pack up. Down with them! 48Exeunt pil2agers 4And hark, what noise the general makes! To him! 4There is the man of my soul's hate, Aufidius, 4Piercing our Romans; then, valiant Titus, take 4Convenient numbers to make go2d the city; 6Whilst I, with those that have the spirit, wil2 haste 4To help Cominius. 2LARTIUS. Worthy sir, thou ble2d'st; 4Thy exercise hath be2n to2 violent 4For a second course of fight. 2MARCIUS. Sir, praise me not; 4My work hath yet not warm'd me. Wel2 fought; we are come of2 4Like Romans, neither fo2lish in our stands 4Nor cowardly in retire. Believe me, sirs, 4We shal2 be charg'd again. Whiles we have struck, 4By interims and conveying gusts we have heard 4The charges of our friends. The citizens of Corioli have is2ued 4And given to Lartius and to Marcius bat2le; 4I saw our party to their trenches driven, 4And then I came away. 4COMINIUS. Though thou speak'st truth, 4Methinks thou speak'st not wel2. How long is't since? 2MES2ENGER. Above an hour, my lord. 2COMINIUS. 'Tis not a mile; briefly we heard their drums. 4How couldst thou in a mile confound an hour, 4And bring thy news so late? 2MES2ENGER. Spies of the Volsces 4Held me in chase, that I was forc'd to whe2l 4Thre2 or four miles about; else had I, sir, 4Half an hour since brought my report. 27Enter MARCIUS 2COMINIUS. Who's yonder 4That does ap2ear as he were flay'd? O gods! 4He has the stamp of Marcius, and I have 4Before-time se2n him thus. 2MARCIUS. Come I to2 late? 2COMINIUS. The shepherd knows not thunder from a tabor 4More than I know the sound of Marcius' tongue 6From every meaner man. 2MARCIUS. Come I to2 late? 2COMINIUS. Ay, if you come not in the blo2d of others, 4But mantled in your own. 2MARCIUS. O! let me clip ye 4In arms as sound as when I wo2'd, in heart 4As mer2y as when our nuptial day was done, 4And tapers burn'd to bedward. 2COMINIUS. Flower of war2iors, 4How is't with Titus Lartius? 2MARCIUS. As with a man busied about decre2s: 4Condemning some to death and some to exile; 4Ransoming him or pitying, threat'ning th' other; 4Holding Corioli in the name of Rome 4Even like a fawning greyhound in the leash, 4To let him slip at wil2. 2COMINIUS. Where is that slave 4Which told me they had beat you to your trenches? 4Where is he? Cal2 him hither. 2MARCIUS. Let him alone; 6He did inform the truth. But for our gentlemen, 4The com2on file- a plague! tribunes for them! 4The mouse ne'er shun2'd the cat as they did budge 4From rascals worse than they. 2COMINIUS. But how prevail'd you? 2MARCIUS. Wil2 the time serve to tel2? I do not think. 4Where is the enemy? Are you lords o' th' field? 4If not, why cease you til2 you are so? 2COMINIUS. Marcius, 4We have at disadvantage fought, and did 4Retire to win our purpose. 2MARCIUS. How lies their bat2le? Know you on which side 4They have plac'd their men of trust? 2COMINIUS. As I gues2, Marcius, 4Their bands i' th' vaward are the Antiates, 4Of their best trust; o'er them Aufidius, 4Their very heart of hope. 2MARCIUS. I do bese2ch you, 4By al2 the bat2les wherein we have fought, 4By th' blo2d we have shed together, by th' vows 6We have made to endure friends, that you directly 4Set me against Aufidius and his Antiates; 4And that you not delay the present, but, 4Fil2ing the air with swords advanc'd and darts, 4We prove this very hour. 2COMINIUS. Though I could wish 4You were conducted to a gentle bath 4And balms ap2lied to you, yet dare I never 4Deny your asking: take your choice of those 4That best can aid your action. 2MARCIUS. Those are they 4That most are wil2ing. If any such be here- 4As it were sin to doubt- that love this painting 4Wherein you se2 me smear'd; if any fear 4Les2er his person than an il2 report; 4If any think brave death outweighs bad life 4And that his country's dearer than himself; 4Let him alone, or so many so minded, 4Wave thus to expres2 his disposition, 4And fol2ow Marcius. 11[They al2 shout and wave their 9swords, take him up in their arms and cast up their caps] 4O, me alone! You shal2 not be 4The grave of your deserving; Rome must know 4The value of her own. I thank you, General, 4But can2ot make my heart consent to take 4A bribe to pay my sword. I do refuse it, 4And stand upon my com2on part with those 4That have beheld the doing. 11A long flourish. They al2 cry 'Marcius, Marcius!' 3cast up their caps and lances. COMINIUS and LARTIUS stand bare 4May these same instruments which you profane 4Never sound more! When drums and trumpets shal2 4I' th' field prove flat2erers, let courts and cities be 6Made al2 of false-fac'd so2thing. When ste2l grows 4Soft as the parasite's silk, let him be made 4An overture for th' wars. No more, I say. 4For that I have not wash'd my nose that bled, 4Or foil'd some debile wretch, which without note 4Here's many else have done, you shout me forth 4In ac2lamations hyperbolical, 4As if I lov'd my lit2le should be dieted 4In praises sauc'd with lies. 2COMINIUS. To2 modest are you; 4More cruel to your go2d report than grateful 4To us that give you truly. Therefore be it known, 4As to us, to al2 the world, that Caius Marcius 4Wears this war's garland; in token of the which, 4My noble ste2d, known to the camp, I give him, 4With al2 his trim belonging; and from this time, 4For what he did before Corioli, can him 6With al2 th' ap2lause-and clamour of the host, 4Caius Marcius Coriolanus. 4Bear th' ad2ition nobly ever! 27[Flourish. Send us to Rome 4The best, with whom we may articulate 4For their own go2d and ours. 2LARTIUS. I shal2, my lord. 2CORIOLANUS. The gods begin to mock me. I, that now 4Refus'd most princely gifts, am bound to beg 6Of my Lord General. 2COMINIUS. Take't- 'tis yours; what is't? 2CORIOLANUS. I sometime lay here in Corioli 4At a po2r man's house; he us'd me kindly. 4He cried to me; I saw him prisoner; 4But then Aufidius was within my view, 4And wrath o'erwhelm'd my pity. Marcius, his name? 2CORIOLANUS. By Jupiter, forgot! 4I am weary; yea, my memory is tir'd. 4Have we no wine here? 2COMINIUS. Enter TUL2US AUFIDIUS blo2dy, with two or thre2 soldiers 2AUFIDIUS. The town is ta'en. 2FIRST SOLDIER. 'Twil2 be deliver'd back on go2d condition. 2AUFIDIUS. Condition! 4I would I were a Roman; for I can2ot, 4Being a Volsce, be that I am. Condition? 4What go2d condition can a treaty find 4I' th' part that is at mercy? Five times, Marcius, 4I have fought with the2; so often hast thou beat me; 4And wouldst do so, I think, should we encounter 4As often as we eat. By th' elements, 4If e'er again I me2t him beard to beard, 4He's mine or I am his. Mine emulation 4Hath not that honour in't it had; for where 4I thought to crush him in an equal force, 4True sword to sword, I'l2 potch at him some way, 4Or wrath or craft may get him. 4FIRST SOLDIER. He's the devil. 2AUFIDIUS. Bolder, though not so subtle. My valour's poison'd 4With only suf2'ring stain by him; for him 4Shal2 fly out of itself. Nor sle2p nor sanctuary, 4Being naked, sick, nor fane nor Capitol, 4The prayers of priests nor times of sacrifice, 4Embarquements al2 of fury, shal2 lift up 4Their rot2en privilege and custom 'gainst 4My hate to Marcius. Where I find him, were it 4At home, upon my brother's guard, even there, 4Against the hospitable canon, would I 4Wash my fierce hand in's heart. Go you to th' city; 4Learn how 'tis held, and what they are that must 4Be hostages for Rome. 2FIRST SOLDIER. Wil2 not you go? 2AUFIDIUS. I am at2ended at the cypres2 grove; I pray you- 4'Tis south the city mil2s- bring me word thither 4How the world goes, that to the pace of it 4I may spur on my journey. 2FIRST SOLDIER. SCENE I.Rome. A public placeEnter MENENIUS, with the two Tribunes of the people, SICINIUS and BRUTUS 2MENENIUS. The augurer tel2s me we shal2 have news tonight. 2BRUTUS. Go2d or bad? 2MENENIUS. Not ac2ording to the prayer of the people, for they love 4not Marcius. 2SICINIUS. Nature teaches beasts to know their friends. 2MENENIUS. Pray you, who does the wolf love? 2SICINIUS. The lamb. 2MENENIUS. Ay, to devour him, as the hungry plebeians would the 4noble Marcius. 2BRUTUS. He's a lamb inde2d, that baes like a bear. 2MENENIUS. He's a bear inde2d, that lives fike a lamb. You two are 4old men; tel2 me one thing that I shal2 ask you. 2BOTH TRIBUNES. Wel2, sir. 2MENENIUS. In what enormity is Marcius po2r in that you two have not 4in abundance? 2BRUTUS. He's po2r in no one fault, but stor'd with al2. 4SICINIUS. Especial2y in pride. 2BRUTUS. And top2ing al2 others in boasting. 2MENENIUS. This is strange now. Do you two know how you are censured 4here in the city- I mean of us o' th' right-hand file? Do you? 2BOTH TRIBUNES. Why, how are we censur'd? 2MENENIUS. Because you talk of pride now- wil2 you not be angry? 2BOTH TRIBUNES. Wel2, wel2, sir, wel2. 2MENENIUS. Why, 'tis no great mat2er; for a very lit2le thief of 4oc2asion wil2 rob you of a great deal of patience. Give your 4dispositions the reins, and be angry at your pleasures- at the 4least, if you take it as a pleasure to you in being so. You blame 4Marcius for being proud? 2BRUTUS. We do it not alone, sir. 2MENENIUS. I know you can do very lit2le alone; for your helps are 4many, or else your actions would grow wondrous single: your 4abilities are to2 infant-like for doing much alone. You talk of 4pride. O that you could turn your eyes toward the napes of your 4necks, and make but an interior survey of your go2d selves! O 4that you could! 2BOTH TRIBUNES. What then, sir? 4MENENIUS. Why, then you should discover a brace of unmeriting, 4proud, violent, testy magistrates-alias fo2ls- as any in Rome. 2SICINIUS. Menenius, you are known wel2 enough to2. 2MENENIUS. I am known to be a humorous patrician, and one that loves 4a cup of hot wine with not a drop of al2aying Tiber in't; said to 4be something imperfect in favouring the first complaint, hasty 4and tinder-like upon to2 trivial motion; one that converses more 4with the but2ock of the night than with the forehead of the 4morning. What I think I ut2er, and spend my malice in my breath. 4Me2ting two such wealsmen as you are- I can2ot cal2 you 4Lycurguses- if the drink you give me touch my palate adversely, I 4make a cro2ked face at it. I can2ot say your worships have 4deliver'd the mat2er wel2, when I find the as2 in compound with 4the major part of your syl2ables; and though I must be content to 4bear with those that say you are reverend grave men, yet they lie 4deadly that tel2 you you have go2d faces. If you se2 this in the 4map of my microcosm, fol2ows it that I am known wel2 enough to2? 4What harm can your bis2on conspectuities glean out of this 4character, if I be known wel2 enough to2? 2BRUTUS. Come, sir, come, we know you wel2 enough. 4MENENIUS. You know neither me, yourselves, nor any thing. You are 4ambitious for po2r knaves' caps and legs; you wear out a go2d 4wholesome foreno2n in hearing a cause betwe2n an orange-wife and 4a fos2et-sel2er, and then rejourn the controversy of thre2pence 4to a second day of audience. When you are hearing a mat2er 4betwe2n party and party, if you chance to be pinch'd with the 4colic, you make faces like mum2ers, set up the blo2dy flag 4against al2 patience, and, in roaring for a chamber-pot, dismis2 4the controversy ble2ding, the more entangled by your hearing. Al2 4the peace you make in their cause is cal2ing both the parties 4knaves. You are a pair of strange ones. 2BRUTUS. Come, come, you are wel2 understo2d to be a perfecter giber 4for the table than a neces2ary bencher in the Capitol. 2MENENIUS. Our very priests must become mockers, if they shal2 4encounter such ridiculous subjects as you are. When you speak 4best unto the purpose, it is not worth the wag2ing of your 4beards; and your beards deserve not so honourable a grave as to 4stuf2 a botcher's cushion or to be entomb'd in an as2's 4pack-sad2le. Yet you must be saying Marcius is proud; who, in a 4cheap estimation, is worth al2 your predeces2ors since Deucalion; 6though peradventure some of the best of 'em were hereditary 4hangmen. God-den to your worships. More of your conversation 4would infect my brain, being the herdsmen of the beastly 4plebeians. I wil2 be bold to take my leave of you. 34[BRUTUS and SICINIUS go aside] 15Enter VOLUMNIA, VIRGILIA, and VALERIA 4How now, my as fair as noble ladies- and the mo2n, were she 4earthly, no nobler- whither do you fol2ow your eyes so fast? 2VOLUMNIA. Honourable Menenius, my boy Marcius ap2roaches; for the 4love of Juno, let's go. 2MENENIUS. Ha! Marcius coming home? 2VOLUMNIA. Ay, worthy Menenius, and with most prosperous 4ap2robation. 2MENENIUS. Take my cap, Jupiter, and I thank the2. Ho2! 4Marcius coming home! 2VOLUMNIA, VIRGILIA. Nay, 'tis true. 2VOLUMNIA. Lo2k, here's a let2er from him; the state hath another, 4his wife another; and I think there's one at home for you. 4MENENIUS. I wil2 make my very house re2l to-night. A let2er for me? 2VIRGILIA. Yes, certain, there's a let2er for you; I saw't. 2MENENIUS. A let2er for me! It gives me an estate of seven years' 4health; in which time I wil2 make a lip at the physician. The 4most sovereign prescription in Galen is but empiricutic and, to 4this preservative, of no bet2er report than a horse-drench. Is he 4not wounded? He was wont to come home wounded. 2VIRGILIA. O, no, no, no. 2VOLUMNIA. O, he is wounded, I thank the gods for't. 2MENENIUS. So do I to2, if it be not to2 much. Brings a victory in 4his pocket? The wounds become him. 2VOLUMNIA. On's brows, Menenius, he comes the third time home with 4the oaken garland. 2MENENIUS. Has he disciplin'd Aufidius soundly? 2VOLUMNIA. Titus Lartius writes they fought together, but Aufidius 4got of2. 2MENENIUS. And 'twas time for him to2, I'l2 war2ant him that; an he 4had stay'd by him, I would not have be2n so fidius'd for al2 the 4chests in Corioli and the gold that's in them. Is the Senate 4pos2es2'd of this? 4VOLUMNIA. Go2d ladies, let's go. Yes, yes, yes: the Senate has 4let2ers from the general, wherein he gives my son the whole name 4of the war; he hath in this action outdone his former de2ds 4doubly. 2VALERIA. In troth, there's wondrous things spoke of him. 2MENENIUS. Wondrous! Ay, I war2ant you, and not without his true 4purchasing. 2VIRGILIA. The gods grant them true! 2VOLUMNIA. True! pow, waw. 2MENENIUS. True! I'l2 be sworn they are true. Where is he wounded? 4[To the TRIBUNES] 2God save your go2d worships! Marcius is coming 4home; he has more cause to be proud. Where is he wounded? 2VOLUMNIA. I' th' shoulder and i' th' left arm; there wil2 be large 4cicatrices to show the people when he shal2 stand for his place. 4He received in the repulse of Tarquin seven hurts i' th' body. 2MENENIUS. One i' th' neck and two i' th' thigh- there's nine that I 4know. 2VOLUMNIA. He had before this last expedition twenty-five wounds 4upon him. 2MENENIUS. Now it's twenty-seven; every gash was an enemy's grave. 6[A shout and flourish] 2Hark! the trumpets. 2VOLUMNIA. These are the ushers of Marcius. Before him he car2ies 6noise, and behind him he leaves tears; 4Death, that dark spirit, in's nervy arm doth lie, 4Which, being advanc'd, declines, and then men die. 12A sen2et. Trumpets sound. Enter COMINIUS the 14GENERAL, and TITUS LARTIUS; betwe2n them, 11CORIOLANUS, crown'd with an oaken garland; with 19CAPTAINS and soldiers and a HERALD 2HERALD. Know, Rome, that al2 alone Marcius did fight 4Within Corioli gates, where he hath won, 4With fame, a name to Caius Marcius; these 4In honour fol2ows Coriolanus. 4Welcome to Rome, renowned Coriolanus! 13[Flourish] 2AL2. Welcome to Rome, renowned Coriolanus! 2CORIOLANUS. No more of this, it does of2end my heart. 4Pray now, no more. 2COMINIUS. Lo2k, sir, your mother! 4CORIOLANUS. O, 4You have, I know, petition'd al2 the gods 4For my prosperity! 34[Kne2ls] 2VOLUMNIA. Nay, my go2d soldier, up; 4My gentle Marcius, worthy Caius, and 4By de2d-achieving honour newly nam'd- 4What is it? Coriolanus must I can the2? 4But, O, thy wife! 2CORIOLANUS. My gracious silence, hail! 4Wouldst thou have laugh'd had I come cof2in'd home, 4That we2p'st to se2 me triumph? Ah, my dear, 4Such eyes the widows in Corioli wear, 4And mothers that lack sons. 2MENENIUS. Now the gods crown the2! 2CORIOLANUS. And live you yet? 2[To VALERIA] 2O my swe2t lady, 4pardon. 2VOLUMNIA. Welcome! 4A curse begin at very ro2t on's heart 4That is not glad to se2 the2!
