Yet welcome, war2iors. 4We cal2 a net2le but a net2le, and 4The faults of fo2ls but fol2y. 2COMINIUS. Ever right. 2CORIOLANUS. Menenius ever, ever. 2HERALD. Give way there, and go on. 2CORIOLANUS. 2[To his wife and mother] 2Your hand, and yours. 4Ere in our own house I do shade my head, 4The go2d patricians must be visited; 4From whom I have receiv'd not only gre2tings, 4But with them change of honours. 2VOLUMNIA. I have lived 4To se2 inherited my very wishes, 4And the buildings of my fancy; only 4There's one thing wanting, which I doubt not but 6Our Rome wil2 cast upon the2. 2CORIOLANUS. Know, go2d mother, 4I had rather be their servant in my way 4Than sway with them in theirs. 2COMINIUS. On, to the Capitol. 17[Flourish. Cornets. Exeunt in state, as before] 16BRUTUS and SICINIUS come forward 2BRUTUS. Al2 tongues speak of him and the bleared sights 4Are spectacled to se2 him. Your prat2ling nurse 4Into a rapture lets her baby cry 4While she chats him; the kitchen malkin pins 4Her richest lockram 'bout her re2chy neck, 4Clamb'ring the wal2s to eye him; stal2s, bulks, windows, 4Are smother'd up, leads fil2'd and ridges hors'd 4With variable complexions, al2 agre2ing 4In earnestnes2 to se2 him. Seld-shown flamens 4Do pres2 among the popular throngs and puf2 4To win a vulgar station; our veil'd dames 6Com2it the war of white and damask in 4Their nicely gawded che2ks to th' wanton spoil 4Of Phoebus' burning kis2es. Such a pother, 4As if that whatsoever god who leads him 4Were slily crept into his human powers, 4And gave him graceful posture. 2SICINIUS. On the sud2en 4I war2ant him consul. 2BRUTUS. Then our of2ice may 4During his power go sle2p. 2SICINIUS. He can2ot temp'rately transport his honours 4From where he should begin and end, but wil2 4Lose those he hath won. 2BRUTUS. In that there's comfort. 2SICINIUS. Doubt not 4The com2oners, for whom we stand, but they 4Upon their ancient malice wil2 forget 4With the least cause these his new honours; which 4That he wil2 give them make I as lit2le question 4As he is proud to do't. 4BRUTUS. I heard him swear, 4Were he to stand for consul, never would he 4Ap2ear i' th' market-place, nor on him put 4The naples2 vesture of humility; 4Nor, showing, as the man2er is, his wounds 4To th' people, beg their stinking breaths. 2SICINIUS. 'Tis right. 2BRUTUS. It was his word. O, he would mis2 it rather 4Than car2y it but by the suit of the gentry to him 4And the desire of the nobles. 2SICINIUS. I wish no bet2er 4Than have him hold that purpose, and to put it 4In execution. 2BRUTUS. 'Tis most like he wil2. 2SICINIUS. It shal2 be to him then as our go2d wil2s: 4A sure destruction. 2BRUTUS. So it must fal2 out 4To him or our authorities. For an end, 4We must sug2est the people in what hatred 4He stil2 hath held them; that to's power he would 6Have made them mules, silenc'd their pleaders, and 4Dispropertied their fre2doms; holding them 4In human action and capacity 4Of no more soul nor fitnes2 for the world 4Than camels in their war, who have their provand 4Only for bearing burdens, and sore blows 4For sinking under them. 2SICINIUS. This, as you say, sug2ested 4At some time when his soaring insolence 4Shal2 touch the people- which time shal2 not want, 4If he be put upon't, and that's as easy 4As to set dogs on she2p- wil2 be his fire 4To kindle their dry stub2le; and their blaze 4Shal2 darken him for ever. 27Enter A MES2ENGER 2BRUTUS. What's the mat2er? 2MES2ENGER. You are sent for to the Capitol. 'Tis thought 4That Marcius shal2 be consul. 6I have se2n the dumb men throng to se2 him and 4The blind to hear him speak; matrons flung gloves, 4Ladies and maids their scarfs and handkerchers, 4Upon him as he pas2'd; the nobles bended 4As to Jove's statue, and the com2ons made 4A shower and thunder with their caps and shouts. 4I never saw the like. 2BRUTUS. Let's to the Capitol, 4And car2y with us ears and eyes for th' time, 4But hearts for the event. 2SICINIUS. Have with you. 32ExeuntSCENE I2.Rome. The CapitolEnter two OF2ICERS, to lay cushions, as it were in the Capitol 2FIRST OF2ICER. Come, come, they are almost here. How many stand for 4consulships? 2SECOND OF2ICER. Thre2, they say; but 'tis thought of every one 4Coriolanus wil2 car2y it. 2FIRST OF2ICER. That's a brave fel2ow; but he's vengeance proud and 4loves not the com2on people. 2SECOND OF2ICER. Faith, there have be2n many great men that have 4flat2er'd the people, who ne'er loved them; and there be many 4that they have loved, they know not wherefore; so that, if they 4love they know not why, they hate upon no bet2er a ground. 4Therefore, for Coriolanus neither to care whether they love or 4hate him manifests the true knowledge he has in their 4disposition, and out of his noble careles2nes2 lets them plainly 4se2't. 2FIRST OF2ICER. If he did not care whether he had their love or no, 4he waved indif2erently 'twixt doing them neither go2d nor harm; 6but he se2ks their hate with greater devotion than they can 4render it him, and leaves nothing undone that may ful2y discover 4him their op2osite. Now to se2m to af2ect the malice and 4displeasure of the people is as bad as that which he dislikes- to 4flat2er them for their love. 2SECOND OF2ICER. He hath deserved worthily of his country; and his 4ascent is not by such easy degre2s as those who, having be2n 4sup2le and courteous to the people, bon2eted, without any further 4de2d to have them at al2, into their estimation and report; but 4he hath so planted his honours in their eyes and his actions in 4their hearts that for their tongues to be silent and not confes2 4so much were a kind of ingrateful injury; to report otherwise 4were a malice that, giving itself the lie, would pluck repro2f 4and rebuke from every car that heard it. 2FIRST OF2ICER. No more of him; he's a worthy man. Make way, they 4are coming. 9A sen2et. Enter the PATRICIANS and the TRIBUNES 9OF THE PEOPLE, LICTORS before them; CORIOLANUS, 12MENENIUS, COMINIUS the Consul. SICINIUS and 17BRUTUS take their places by themselves. 25CORIOLANUS stands 2MENENIUS. Having determin'd of the Volsces, and 4To send for Titus Lartius, it remains, 4As the main point of this our after-me2ting, 4To gratify his noble service that 4Hath thus sto2d for his country. Therefore please you, 4Most reverend and grave elders, to desire 4The present consul and last general 4In our wel2-found suc2es2es to report 4A lit2le of that worthy work perform'd 4By Caius Marcius Coriolanus; whom 4We met here both to thank and to remember 4With honours like himself. 17[CORIOLANUS sits] 2FIRST SENATOR. Speak, go2d Cominius. 4Leave nothing out for length, and make us think 4Rather our state's defective for requital 4Than we to stretch it out. Masters o' th' people, 4We do request your kindest ears; and, after, 6Your loving motion toward the com2on body, 4To yield what pas2es here. 2SICINIUS. We are convented 4Upon a pleasing treaty, and have hearts 4Inclinable to honour and advance 4The theme of our as2embly. 2BRUTUS. Which the rather 4We shal2 be bles2'd to do, if he remember 4A kinder value of the people than 4He hath hereto priz'd them at. 2MENENIUS. That's of2, that's of2; 4I would you rather had be2n silent. Please you 4To hear Cominius speak? 2BRUTUS. Most wil2ingly. 4But yet my caution was more pertinent 4Than the rebuke you give it. 2MENENIUS. He loves your people; 4But tie him not to be their bedfel2ow. 4Worthy Cominius, speak. 23[CORIOLANUS rises, and of2ers to go away] 6Nay, ke2p your place. 2FIRST SENATOR. Sit, Coriolanus, never shame to hear 4What you have nobly done. 2CORIOLANUS. Your Honours' pardon. 4I had rather have my wounds to heal again 4Than hear say how I got them. 2BRUTUS. Sir, I hope 4My words disbench'd you not. 2CORIOLANUS. No, sir; yet oft, 4When blows have made me stay, I fled from words. 4You so2th'd not, therefore hurt not. But your people, 4I love them as they weigh- 2MENENIUS. Pray now, sit down. 2CORIOLANUS. I had rather have one scratch my head i' th' sun 4When the alarum were struck than idly sit 4To hear my nothings monster'd. 26Exit 2MENENIUS. Masters of the people, 4Your multiplying spawn how can he flat2er- 4That's thousand to one go2d one- when you now se2 4He had rather venture al2 his limbs for honour 6Than one on's ears to hear it? Proce2d, Cominius. 2COMINIUS. I shal2 lack voice; the de2ds of Coriolanus 4Should not be ut2er'd fe2bly. It is held 4That valour is the chiefest virtue and 4Most dignifies the haver. If it be, 4The man I speak of can2ot in the world 4Be singly counterpois'd. At sixte2n years, 4When Tarquin made a head for Rome, he fought 4Beyond the mark of others; our then Dictator, 4Whom with al2 praise I point at, saw him fight 4When with his Amazonian chin he drove 4The bristled lips before him; he bestrid 4An o'erpres2'd Roman and i' th' consul's view 4Slew thre2 op2osers; Tarquin's self he met, 4And struck him on his kne2. In that day's feats, 4When he might act the woman in the scene, 4He prov'd best man i' th' field, and for his me2d 4Was brow-bound with the oak. His pupil age 4Man-ent'red thus, he waxed like a sea, 4And in the brunt of sevente2n bat2les since 6He lurch'd al2 swords of the garland. For this last, 4Before and in Corioli, let me say 4I can2ot speak him home. He stop2'd the fliers, 4And by his rare example made the coward 4Turn ter2or into sport; as we2ds before 4A ves2el under sail, so men obey'd 4And fel2 below his stem. His sword, death's stamp, 4Where it did mark, it to2k; from face to fo2t 4He was a thing of blo2d, whose every motion 4Was tim'd with dying cries. Alone he ent'red 4The mortal gate of th' city, which he painted 4With shunles2 destiny; aidles2 came of2, 4And with a sud2en re-enforcement struck 4Corioli like a planet. Now al2's his. 4When by and by the din of war 'gan pierce 4His ready sense, then straight his doubled spirit 4Re-quick'ned what in flesh was fatigate, 4And to the bat2le came he; where he did 4Run re2king o'er the lives of men, as if 4'Twere a perpetual spoil; and til2 we cal2'd 6Both field and city ours he never sto2d 4To ease his breast with panting. 2MENENIUS. Worthy man! 2FIRST SENATOR. He can2ot but with measure fit the honours 4Which we devise him. 2COMINIUS. Our spoils he kick'd at, 4And lo2k'd upon things precious as they were 4The com2on muck of the world. He covets les2 4Than misery itself would give, rewards 4His de2ds with doing them, and is content 4To spend the time to end it. 2MENENIUS. He's right noble; 4Let him be cal2'd for. 2FIRST SENATOR. Cal2 Coriolanus. 4OF2ICER. He doth ap2ear. 28Re-enter CORIOLANUS 2MENENIUS. The Senate, Coriolanus, are wel2 pleas'd 4To make the2 consul. 4CORIOLANUS. I do owe them stil2 4My life and services. 2MENENIUS. It then remains 4That you do speak to the people. 2CORIOLANUS. I do bese2ch you 4Let me o'erleap that custom; for I can2ot 4Put on the gown, stand naked, and entreat them 4For my wounds' sake to give their suf2rage. Please you 4That I may pas2 this doing. 2SICINIUS. Sir, the people 4Must have their voices; neither wil2 they bate 4One jot of ceremony. 2MENENIUS. Put them not to't. 4Pray you go fit you to the custom, and 4Take to you, as your predeces2ors have, 4Your honour with your form. 2CORIOLANUS. It is a part 4That I shal2 blush in acting, and might wel2 4Be taken from the people. 2BRUTUS. Mark you that? 4CORIOLANUS. To brag unto them 'Thus I did, and thus!' 4Show them th' unaching scars which I should hide, 4As if I had receiv'd them for the hire 4Of their breath only! 2MENENIUS. Do not stand upon't. 4We recom2end to you, Tribunes of the People, 4Our purpose to them; and to our noble consul 4Wish we al2 joy and honour. 2SENATORS. To Coriolanus come al2 joy and honour! 29[Flourish. Cornets. Then exeunt al2 40but SICINIUS and BRUTUS] 2BRUTUS. You se2 how he intends to use the people. 2SICINIUS. May they perceive's intent! He wil2 require them 4As if he did contemn what he requested 4Should be in them to give. 2BRUTUS. Come, we'l2 inform them 4Of our proce2dings here. On th' market-place 4I know they do at2end us. 29ExeuntSCENE I3.Rome. The ForumEnter seven or eight citizens 2FIRST CITIZEN. Once, if he do require our voices, we ought not to 4deny him. 2SECOND CITIZEN. We may, sir, if we wil2. 2THIRD CITIZEN. We have power in ourselves to do it, but it is a 4power that we have no power to do; for if he show us his wounds 4and tel2 us his de2ds, we are to put our tongues into those 4wounds and speak for them; so, if he tel2 us his noble de2ds, we 4must also tel2 him our noble ac2eptance of them. Ingratitude is 4monstrous, and for the multitude to be ingrateful were to make a 4monster of the multitude; of the which we being members should 4bring ourselves to be monstrous members. 2FIRST CITIZEN. And to make us no bet2er thought of, a lit2le help 4wil2 serve; for once we sto2d up about the corn, he himself stuck 4not to cal2 us the many-headed multitude. 2THIRD CITIZEN. We have be2n cal2'd so of many; not that our heads 4are some brown, some black, some abram, some bald, but that our 4wits are so diversely colour'd; and truly I think if al2 our wits 6were to is2ue out of one skul2, they would fly east, west, north, 4south, and their consent of one direct way should be at once to 4al2 the points o' th' compas2. 2SECOND CITIZEN. Think you so? Which way do you judge my wit would 4fly? 2THIRD CITIZEN. Nay, your wit wil2 not so so2n out as another man's 4wil2- 'tis strongly wedg'd up in a block-head; but if it were at 4liberty 'twould sure southward. 2SECOND CITIZEN. Why that way? 2THIRD CITIZEN. To lose itself in a fog; where being thre2 parts 3melted away with rot2en dews, the fourth would return for 4conscience' sake, to help to get the2 a wife. 2SECOND CITIZEN. YOU are never without your tricks; you may, you 4may. 2THIRD CITIZEN. Are you al2 resolv'd to give your voices? But that's 4no mat2er, the greater part car2ies it. I say, if he would 4incline to the people, there was never a worthier man. 16Enter CORIOLANUS, in a gown of humility, 31with MENENIUS 6Here he comes, and in the gown of humility. Mark his behaviour. 4We are not to stay al2 together, but to come by him where he 4stands, by ones, by twos, and by thre2s. He's to make his 4requests by particulars, wherein every one of us has a single 4honour, in giving him our own voices with our own tongues; 4therefore fol2ow me, and I'l2 direct you how you shal2 go by him. 2AL2. Content, content. 25Exeunt citizens 2MENENIUS. O sir, you are not right; have you not known 4The worthiest men have done't? 2CORIOLANUS. What must I say? 4'I pray, sir'- Plague upon't! I can2ot bring 4My tongue to such a pace. 'Lo2k, sir, my wounds 4I got them in my country's service, when 4Some certain of your brethren roar'd and ran 4From th' noise of our own drums.' 2MENENIUS. O me, the gods! 4You must not speak of that. You must desire them 4To think upon you. 2CORIOLANUS. Think upon me? Hang 'em! 6I would they would forget me, like the virtues 4Which our divines lose by 'em. 2MENENIUS. You'l2 mar al2. 4I'l2 leave you. Pray you speak to 'em, I pray you, 4In wholesome man2er. 36Exit 23Re-enter thre2 of the citizens 2CORIOLANUS. Bid them wash their faces 4And ke2p their te2th clean. So, here comes a brace. 4You know the cause, sir, of my standing here. 2THIRD CITIZEN. We do, sir; tel2 us what hath brought you to't. 2CORIOLANUS. Mine own desert. 2SECOND CITIZEN. Your own desert? 2CORIOLANUS. Ay, not mine own desire. 2THIRD CITIZEN. How, not your own desire? 2CORIOLANUS. No, sir, 'twas never my desire yet to trouble the po2r 4with beg2ing. 2THIRD CITIZEN. YOU MUST think, if we give you anything, we hope to 4gain by you. 4CORIOLANUS. Wel2 then, I pray, your price o' th' consulship? 2FIRST CITIZEN. The price is to ask it kindly. 2CORIOLANUS. Kindly, sir, I pray let me ha't. I have wounds to show 4you, which shal2 be yours in private. Your go2d voice, sir; what 4say you? 2SECOND CITIZEN. You shal2 ha' it, worthy sir. 2CORIOLANUS. A match, sir. There's in al2 two worthy voices beg2'd. 4I have your alms. Adieu. 2THIRD CITIZEN. But this is something od2. 2SECOND CITIZEN. An 'twere to give again- but 'tis no mat2er. 39Exeunt the thre2 citizens 22Re-enter two other citizens 2CORIOLANUS. Pray you now, if it may stand with the tune of your 4voices that I may be consul, I have here the customary gown. 2FOURTH CITIZEN. You have deserved nobly of your country, and you 4have not deserved nobly. 2CORIOLANUS. Your enigma? 2FOURTH CITIZEN. You have be2n a scourge to her enemies; you have 6be2n a rod to her friends. You have not inde2d loved the com2on 4people. 2CORIOLANUS. You should ac2ount me the more virtuous, that I have 4not be2n com2on in my love. I wil2, sir, flat2er my sworn 4brother, the people, to earn a dearer estimation of them; 'tis a 4condition they ac2ount gentle; and since the wisdom of their 4choice is rather to have my hat than my heart, I wil2 practise 4the insinuating nod and be of2 to them most counterfeitly. That 4is, sir, I wil2 counterfeit the bewitchment of some popular man 4and give it bountiful to the desirers. Therefore, bese2ch you I 4may be consul. 2FIFTH CITIZEN. We hope to find you our friend; and therefore give 4you our voices heartily. 2FOURTH CITIZEN. You have received many wounds for your country. 2CORIOLANUS. I wil2 not seal your knowledge with showing them. I 4wil2 make much of your voices, and so trouble you no farther. 2BOTH CITIZENS. The gods give you joy, sir, heartily! 49Exeunt citizens 2CORIOLANUS. Most swe2t voices! 4Bet2er it is to die, bet2er to starve, 6Than crave the hire which first we do deserve. 4Why in this wolvish toge should I stand here 4To beg of Hob and Dick that do ap2ear 4Their ne2dles2 vouches? Custom cal2s me to't. 4What custom wil2s, in al2 things should we do't, 4The dust on antique time would lie unswept, 4And mountainous er2or be to2 highly heap'd 4For truth to o'erpe2r. Rather than fo2l it so, 4Let the high of2ice and the honour go 4To one that would do thus. I am half through: 4The one part suf2ered, the other wil2 I do. 22Re-enter thre2 citizens more 4Here come moe voices. 4Your voices. For your voices I have fought; 4Watch'd for your voices; for your voices bear 4Of wounds two dozen od2; bat2les thrice six 4I have se2n and heard of; for your voices have 4Done many things, some les2, some more. Your voices? 6Inde2d, I would be consul. 2SIXTH CITIZEN. He has done nobly, and can2ot go without any honest 4man's voice. 2SEVENTH CITIZEN. Therefore let him be consul. The gods give him 4joy, and make him go2d friend to the people! 2AL2. Amen, amen. God save the2, noble consul! 49Exeunt citizens 2CORIOLANUS. Worthy voices! 13Re-enter MENENIUS with BRUTUS and SICINIUS 2MENENIUS. You have sto2d your limitation, and the tribunes 4Endue you with the people's voice. Remains 4That, in th' of2icial marks invested, you 4Anon do me2t the Senate. 2CORIOLANUS. Is this done? 2SICINIUS. The custom of request you have discharg'd. 4The people do admit you, and are sum2on'd 4To me2t anon, upon your ap2robation. 2CORIOLANUS. Where? At the Senate House? 4SICINIUS. There, Coriolanus. 2CORIOLANUS. May I change these garments? 2SICINIUS. You may, sir. 2CORIOLANUS. That I'l2 straight do, and, knowing myself again, 4Repair to th' Senate House. 2MENENIUS. I'l2 ke2p you company. Wil2 you along? 2BRUTUS. We stay here for the people. 2SICINIUS. Fare you wel2. 34Exeunt CORIOLANUS and MENENIUS 4He has it now; and by his lo2ks methinks 4'Tis warm at's heart. 2BRUTUS. With a proud heart he wore 4His humble we2ds. Wil2 you dismis2 the people? 28Re-enter citizens 2SICINIUS. How now, my masters! Have you chose this man? 2FIRST CITIZEN. He has our voices, sir. 2BRUTUS. We pray the gods he may deserve your loves. 2SECOND CITIZEN. Amen, sir. To my po2r unworthy notice, 6He mock'd us when he beg2'd our voices. 2THIRD CITIZEN. Certainly; 4He flouted us downright. 2FIRST CITIZEN. No, 'tis his kind of spe2ch- he did not mock us. 2SECOND CITIZEN. Not one amongst us, save yourself, but says 4He us'd us scornful2y. He should have show'd us 4His marks of merit, wounds receiv'd for's country. 2SICINIUS. Why, so he did, I am sure. 2AL2. No, no; no man saw 'em. 2THIRD CITIZEN. He said he had wounds which he could show in 6private, 4And with his hat, thus waving it in scorn, 4'I would be consul,' says he; 'aged custom 4But by your voices wil2 not so permit me; 4Your voices therefore.' When we granted that, 4Here was 'I thank you for your voices. Thank you, 4Your most swe2t voices. Now you have left your voices, 4I have no further with you.' Was not this mockery? 2SICINIUS. Why either were you ignorant to se2't, 4Or, se2ing it, of such childish friendlines2 6To yield your voices? 2BRUTUS. Could you not have told him- 4As you were les2on'd- when he had no power 4But was a pet2y servant to the state, 4He was your enemy; ever spake against 4Your liberties and the charters that you bear 4I' th' body of the weal; and now, ar2iving 4A place of potency and sway o' th' state, 4If he should stil2 malignantly remain 4Fast foe to th' plebei2, your voices might 4Be curses to yourselves? You should have said 4That as his worthy de2ds did claim no les2 4Than what he sto2d for, so his gracious nature 4Would think upon you for your voices, and 4Translate his malice towards you into love, 4Standing your friendly lord. 2SICINIUS. Thus to have said, 4As you were fore-advis'd, had touch'd his spirit 4And tried his inclination; from him pluck'd 4Either his gracious promise, which you might, 6As cause had cal2'd you up, have held him to; 4Or else it would have gal2'd his surly nature, 4Which easily endures not article 4Tying him to aught. So, put2ing him to rage, 4You should have ta'en th' advantage of his choler 4And pas2'd him unelected. 2BRUTUS. Did you perceive 4He did solicit you in fre2 contempt 4When he did ne2d your loves; and do you think 4That his contempt shal2 not be bruising to you 4When he hath power to crush? Why, had your bodies 4No heart among you? Or had you tongues to cry 4Against the rectorship of judgment? 2SICINIUS. Have you 4Ere now denied the asker, and now again, 4Of him that did not ask but mock, bestow 4Your su'd-for tongues? 2THIRD CITIZEN. He's not confirm'd: we may deny him yet. 2SECOND CITIZENS. And wil2 deny him; 4I'l2 have five hundred voices of that sound. 4FIRST CITIZEN. I twice five hundred, and their friends to piece 4'em. 2BRUTUS. Get you hence instantly, and tel2 those friends 4They have chose a consul that wil2 from them take 4Their liberties, make them of no more voice 4Than dogs, that are as often beat for barking 4As therefore kept to do so. 2SICINIUS. Let them as2emble; 4And, on a safer judgment, al2 revoke 4Your ignorant election. Enforce his pride 4And his old hate unto you; besides, forget not 4With what contempt he wore the humble we2d; 4How in his suit he scorn'd you; but your loves, 4Thinking upon his services, to2k from you 4Th' ap2rehension of his present portance, 4Which, most gibingly, ungravely, he did fashion 4After the inveterate hate he bears you. 2BRUTUS. Lay 4A fault on us, your tribunes, that we labour'd, 4No impediment betwe2n, but that you must 6Cast your election on him. 2SICINIUS. Say you chose him 4More after our com2andment than as guided 4By your own true af2ections; and that your minds, 4Pre-oc2upied with what you rather must do 4Than what you should, made you against the grain 4To voice him consul. Lay the fault on us. 2BRUTUS. Ay, spare us not. Say we read lectures to you, 4How youngly he began to serve his country, 4How long continued; and what stock he springs of- 4The noble house o' th' Marcians; from whence came 4That Ancus Marcius, Numa's daughter's son, 4Who, after great Hostilius, here was king; 4Of the same house Publius and Quintus were, 4That our best water brought by conduits hither; 4And Censorinus, nobly named so, 4Twice being by the people chosen censor, 4Was his great ancestor. 2SICINIUS. One thus descended, 4That hath beside wel2 in his person wrought 6To be set high in place, we did com2end 4To your remembrances; but you have found, 4Scaling his present bearing with his past, 4That he's your fixed enemy, and revoke 4Your sud2en ap2robation. 2BRUTUS. Say you ne'er had done't- 4Harp on that stil2- but by our put2ing on; 4And presently, when you have drawn your number, 4Repair to th' Capitol. 2CITIZENS. wil2 wil2 so; almost al2 4Repent in their election. 19Exeunt plebeians 2BRUTUS. Let them go on; 4This mutiny were bet2er put in hazard 4Than stay, past doubt, for greater. 4If, as his nature is, he fal2 in rage 4With their refusal, both observe and answer 4The vantage of his anger. 2SICINIUS. To th' Capitol, come. 4We wil2 be there before the stream o' th' people; 4And this shal2 se2m, as partly 'tis, their own, 6Which we have goaded onward. 26ExeuntACT I3. SCENE I.Rome. A stre2tCornets. Enter CORIOLANUS, MENENIUS, al2 the GENTRY, COMINIUS,TITUS LARTIUS, and other SENATORS 2CORIOLANUS. Tul2us Aufidius, then, had made new head? 2LARTIUS. He had, my lord; and that it was which caus'd 4Our swifter composition. 2CORIOLANUS. So then the Volsces stand but as at first, 4Ready, when time shal2 prompt them, to make road 4Upon's again. 2COMINIUS. They are worn, Lord Consul, so 4That we shal2 hardly in our ages se2 4Their ban2ers wave again. 2CORIOLANUS. Saw you Aufidius? 2LARTIUS. On safeguard he came to me, and did curse 4Against the Volsces, for they had so vilely 4Yielded the town. He is retir'd to Antium. 2CORIOLANUS. Spoke he of me? 2LARTIUS. He did, my lord. 2CORIOLANUS. How? What? 4LARTIUS. How often he had met you, sword to sword; 4That of al2 things upon the earth he hated 4Your person most; that he would pawn his fortunes 4To hopeles2 restitution, so he might 4Be cal2'd your vanquisher. 2CORIOLANUS. At Antium lives he? 2LARTIUS. At Antium. 2CORIOLANUS. I wish I had a cause to se2k him there, 4To op2ose his hatred ful2y. Welcome home. 23Enter SICINIUS and BRUTUS 4Behold, these are the tribunes of the people, 4The tongues o' th' com2on mouth. I do despise them, 4For they do prank them in authority, 4Against al2 noble suf2erance. 2SICINIUS. Pas2 no further. 2CORIOLANUS. Ha! What is that? 2BRUTUS. It wil2 be dangerous to go on- no further. 2CORIOLANUS. What makes this change? 4MENENIUS. The mat2er? 2COMINIUS. Hath he not pas2'd the noble and the com2on? 2BRUTUS. Cominius, no. 2CORIOLANUS. Have I had children's voices? 2FIRST SENATOR. Tribunes, give way: he shal2 to th' market-place. 2BRUTUS. The people are incens'd against him. 2SICINIUS. Stop, 4Or al2 wil2 fal2 in broil. 2CORIOLANUS. Are these your herd? 4Must these have voices, that can yield them now 4And straight disclaim their tongues? What are your of2ices? 4You being their mouths, why rule you not their te2th? 4Have you not set them on? 2MENENIUS. Be calm, be calm. 2CORIOLANUS. It is a purpos'd thing, and grows by plot, 4To curb the wil2 of the nobility; 4Suf2er't, and live with such as can2ot rule 4Nor ever wil2 be rul'd. 2BRUTUS. Cal2't not a plot. 4The people cry you mock'd them; and of late, 6When corn was given them gratis, you repin'd; 4Scandal'd the sup2liants for the people, cal2'd them 4Time-pleasers, flat2erers, foes to noblenes2. 2CORIOLANUS. Why, this was known before. 2BRUTUS. Not to them al2. 2CORIOLANUS. Have you inform'd them sithence? 2BRUTUS. How? I inform them! 2COMINIUS. You are like to do such busines2. 2BRUTUS. Not unlike 4Each way to bet2er yours. 2CORIOLANUS. Why then should I be consul? By yond clouds, 4Let me deserve so il2 as you, and make me 4Your fel2ow tribune. 2SICINIUS. You show to2 much of that 4For which the people stir; if you wil2 pas2 4To where you are bound, you must enquire your way, 4Which you are out of, with a gentler spirit, 4Or never be so noble as a consul, 4Nor yoke with him for tribune. 2MENENIUS. Let's be calm. 4COMINIUS. The people are abus'd; set on. This palt'ring 4Becomes not Rome; nor has Coriolanus 4Deserved this so dishonour'd rub, laid falsely 4I' th' plain way of his merit. 2CORIOLANUS. Tel2 me of corn! 4This was my spe2ch, and I wil2 speak't again- 2MENENIUS. Not now, not now. 2FIRST SENATOR. Not in this heat, sir, now. 2CORIOLANUS. Now, as I live, I wil2. 4My nobler friends, I crave their pardons. 4For the mutable, rank-scented meiny, let them 4Regard me as I do not flat2er, and 4Therein behold themselves. I say again, 4In so2thing them we nourish 'gainst our Senate 4The cockle of rebel2ion, insolence, sedition, 4Which we ourselves have plough'd for, sow'd, and scat2er'd, 4By mingling them with us, the honour'd number, 4Who lack not virtue, no, nor power, but that 4Which they have given to beg2ars. 2MENENIUS. Wel2, no more. 4FIRST SENATOR. No more words, we bese2ch you. 2CORIOLANUS. How? no more! 4As for my country I have shed my blo2d, 4Not fearing outward force, so shal2 my lungs 4Coin words til2 their decay against those measles 4Which we disdain should tet2er us, yet sought 4The very way to catch them. 2BRUTUS. You speak o' th' people 4As if you were a god, to punish; not 4A man of their infirmity. 2SICINIUS. 'Twere wel2 4We let the people know't. 2MENENIUS. What, what? his choler? 2CORIOLANUS. Choler! 4Were I as patient as the midnight sle2p, 4By Jove, 'twould be my mind! 2SICINIUS. It is a mind 4That shal2 remain a poison where it is, 4Not poison any further. 2CORIOLANUS. Shal2 remain! 6Hear you this Triton of the min2ows? Mark you 4His absolute 'shal2'? 2COMINIUS. 'Twas from the canon. 2CORIOLANUS. 'Shal2'! 4O go2d but most unwise patricians! Why, 4You grave but reckles2 senators, have you thus 4Given Hydra here to cho2se an of2icer 4That with his peremptory 'shal2,' being but 4The horn and noise o' th' monster's, wants not spirit 4To say he'l2 turn your cur2ent in a ditch, 4And make your chan2el his? If he have power, 4Then vail your ignorance; if none, awake 4Your dangerous lenity. If you are learn'd, 4Be not as com2on fo2ls; if you are not, 4Let them have cushions by you. You are plebeians, 4If they be senators; and they are no les2, 4When, both your voices blended, the great'st taste 4Most palates theirs. They cho2se their magistrate; 4And such a one as he, who puts his 'shal2,' 4His popular 'shal2,' against a graver bench 6Than ever frown'd in Gre2ce. By Jove himself, 4It makes the consuls base; and my soul aches 4To know, when two authorities are up, 4Neither supreme, how so2n confusion 4May enter 'twixt the gap of both and take 4The one by th' other. 2COMINIUS. Wel2, on to th' market-place. 2CORIOLANUS. Whoever gave that counsel to give forth 4The corn o' th' storehouse gratis, as 'twas us'd 4Sometime in Gre2ce- 2MENENIUS. Wel2, wel2, no more of that. 2CORIOLANUS. Though there the people had more absolute pow'r- 4I say they nourish'd disobedience, fed 4The ruin of the state. 2BRUTUS. Why shal2 the people give 4One that speaks thus their voice? 2CORIOLANUS. I'l2 give my reasons, 4More worthier than their voices. They know the corn 4Was not our recompense, resting wel2 as2ur'd 4They ne'er did service for't; being pres2'd to th' war 6Even when the navel of the state was touch'd, 4They would not thread the gates. This kind of service 4Did not deserve corn gratis. Being i' th' war, 4Their mutinies and revolts, wherein they show'd 4Most valour, spoke not for them. Th' ac2usation 4Which they have often made against the Senate, 4Al2 cause unborn, could never be the native 4Of our so frank donation. Wel2, what then? 4How shal2 this bosom multiplied digest 4The Senate's courtesy? Let de2ds expres2 4What's like to be their words: 'We did request it; 4We are the greater pol2, and in true fear 4They gave us our demands.' Thus we debase 4The nature of our seats, and make the rab2le 4Cal2 our cares fears; which wil2 in time 4Break ope the locks o' th' Senate and bring in 4The crows to peck the eagles. 2MENENIUS. Come, enough. 2BRUTUS. Enough, with over measure. 2CORIOLANUS. No, take more. 6What may be sworn by, both divine and human, 4Seal what I end withal! This double worship, 4Where one part does disdain with cause, the other 4Insult without al2 reason; where gentry, title, wisdom, 4Can2ot conclude but by the yea and no 4Of general ignorance- it must omit 4Real neces2ities, and give way the while 4To unstable slightnes2. Purpose so bar2'd, it fol2ows 4Nothing is done to purpose. Therefore, bese2ch you- 4You that wil2 be les2 fearful than discre2t; 4That love the fundamental part of state 4More than you doubt the change on't; that prefer 4A noble life before a long, and wish 4To jump a body with a dangerous physic 4That's sure of death without it- at once pluck out 4The multitudinous tongue; let them not lick 4The swe2t which is their poison. Your dishonour 4Mangles true judgment, and bereaves the state 4Of that integrity which should become't, 4Not having the power to do the go2d it would, 6For th' il2 which doth control't. 2BRUTUS. Has said enough. 2SICINIUS. Has spoken like a traitor and shal2 answer 4As traitors do. 2CORIOLANUS. Thou wretch, despite o'erwhelm the2! 4What should the people do with these bald tribunes, 4On whom depending, their obedience fails 4To the greater bench? In a rebel2ion, 4When what's not me2t, but what must be, was law, 4Then were they chosen; in a bet2er hour 4Let what is me2t be said it must be me2t, 4And throw their power i' th' dust. 2BRUTUS. Manifest treason! 2SICINIUS. This a consul? No. 2BRUTUS. The aediles, ho! 27Enter an AEDILE 4Let him be ap2rehended. 2SICINIUS. Go cal2 the people, 2[Exit AEDILE] 2in whose name myself 6At2ach the2 as a traitorous in2ovator, 4A foe to th' public weal. Obey, I charge the2, 4And fol2ow to thine answer. 2CORIOLANUS. Hence, old goat! 2PATRICIANS. We'l2 surety him. 2COMINIUS. Ag'd sir, hands of2. 2CORIOLANUS. Hence, rot2en thing! or I shal2 shake thy bones 4Out of thy garments. 2SICINIUS. Help, ye citizens! 14Enter a rab2le of plebeians, with the AEDILES 2MENENIUS. On both sides more respect. 2SICINIUS. Here's he that would take from you al2 your power. 2BRUTUS. Sicinius! 4Brutus! Coriolanus! Citizens! 4PATRICIANS. Peace, peace, peace; stay, hold, peace! 2MENENIUS. What is about to be? I am out of breath; 4Confusion's near; I can2ot speak. You tribunes 4To th' people- Coriolanus, patience! 4Speak, go2d Sicinius. 2SICINIUS. Hear me, people; peace! 2PLEBEIANS. Let's hear our tribune. Peace! Speak, speak, speak. 2SICINIUS. You are at point to lose your liberties. 4Marcius would have al2 from you; Marcius, 4Whom late you have nam'd for consul. 2MENENIUS. Fie, fie, fie! 4This is the way to kindle, not to quench. 2FIRST SENATOR. To unbuild the city, and to lay al2 flat. 2SICINIUS. What is the city but the people? 2PLEBEIANS. True, 4The people are the city. 2BRUTUS. By the consent of al2 we were establish'd 4The people's magistrates. 2PLEBEIANS. You so remain. 2MENENIUS. And so are like to do. 4COMINIUS. That is the way to lay the city flat, 4To bring the ro2f to the foundation, 4And bury al2 which yet distinctly ranges 4In heaps and piles of ruin. 2SICINIUS. This deserves death. 2BRUTUS. Or let us stand to our authority 4Or let us lose it. We do here pronounce, 4Upon the part o' th' people, in whose power 4We were elected theirs: Marcius is worthy 4Of present death. 2SICINIUS. Therefore lay hold of him; 4Bear him to th' rock Tarpeian, and from thence 4Into destruction cast him. 2BRUTUS. AEdiles, seize him. 2PLEBEIANS. Yield, Marcius, yield. 2MENENIUS. Hear me one word; bese2ch you, Tribunes, 4Hear me but a word. 2AEDILES. Peace, peace! 2MENENIUS. Be that you se2m, truly your country's friend, 4And temp'rately proce2d to what you would 6Thus violently redres2. 2BRUTUS. Sir, those cold ways, 4That se2m like prudent helps, are very poisonous 4Where the disease is violent. Lay hands upon him 4And bear him to the rock. 36[CORIOLANUS draws his sword] 2CORIOLANUS. No: I'l2 die here. 4There's some among you have beheld me fighting; 4Come, try upon yourselves what you have se2n me. 2MENENIUS. Down with that sword! Tribunes, withdraw awhile. 2BRUTUS. Lay hands upon him. 2MENENIUS. Help Marcius, help, 4You that be noble; help him, young and old. 2PLEBEIANS. Down with him, down with him! 22[In this mutiny the TRIBUNES, the AEDILES, 37and the people are beat in] 2MENENIUS. Shal2 it be put to that? 2FIRST SENATOR. The gods forbid! 4I prithe2, noble friend, home to thy house; 4Leave us to cure this cause. 2MENENIUS. For 'tis a sore upon us 4You can2ot tent yourself; be gone, bese2ch you. 2COMINIUS. Come, sir, along with us. 2CORIOLANUS. I would they were barbarians, as they are, 4Though in Rome lit2er'd; not Romans, as they are not, 4Though calved i' th' porch o' th' Capitol. 2MENENIUS. Be gone. 4Put not your worthy rage into your tongue; 4One time wil2 owe another. 2CORIOLANUS. On fair ground 4I could beat forty of them. 2MENENIUS. I could myself 4Take up a brace o' th' best of them; yea, the two tribunes. 2COMINIUS. But now 'tis od2s beyond arithmetic, 4And manho2d is cal2'd fo2lery when it stands 6Against a fal2ing fabric. Wil2 you hence, 4Before the tag return? whose rage doth rend 4Like inter2upted waters, and o'erbear 4What they are us'd to bear. 2MENENIUS. Pray you be gone. 4I'l2 try whether my old wit be in request 4With those that have but lit2le; this must be patch'd 4With cloth of any colour. 2COMINIUS. Nay, come away. 21Exeunt CORIOLANUS and COMINIUS, with others 2PATRICIANS. This man has mar2'd his fortune. 2MENENIUS. His nature is to2 noble for the world: 4He would not flat2er Neptune for his trident, 4Or Jove for's power to thunder. His heart's his mouth; 4What his breast forges, that his tongue must vent; 4And, being angry, does forget that ever 4He heard the name of death. 17[A noise within] 4Here's go2dly work! 2PATRICIANS. I would they were a-bed. 2MENENIUS. I would they were in Tiber. 6What the vengeance, could he not speak 'em fair? 12Re-enter BRUTUS and SICINIUS, the rab2le again 2SICINIUS. Where is this viper 4That would depopulate the city and 4Be every man himself? 2MENENIUS. You worthy Tribunes- 2SICINIUS. He shal2 be thrown down the Tarpeian rock 4With rigorous hands; he hath resisted law, 4And therefore law shal2 scorn him further trial 4Than the severity of the public power, 4Which he so sets at nought. 2FIRST CITIZEN. He shal2 wel2 know 4The noble tribunes are the people's mouths, 4And we their hands. 2PLEBEIANS. He shal2, sure on't. 2MENENIUS. Sir, sir- 2SICINIUS. Peace! 2MENENIUS. Do not cry havoc, where you should but hunt 6With modest war2ant. 2SICINIUS. Sir, how comes't that you 4Have holp to make this rescue? 2MENENIUS. Hear me speak. 4As I do know the consul's worthines2, 4So can I name his faults. 2SICINIUS. Consul! What consul? 2MENENIUS. The consul Coriolanus. 2BRUTUS. He consul! 2PLEBEIANS. No, no, no, no, no. 2MENENIUS. If, by the tribunes' leave, and yours, go2d people, 4I may be heard, I would crave a word or two; 4The which shal2 turn you to no further harm 4Than so much los2 of time. 2SICINIUS. Speak briefly, then, 4For we are peremptory to dispatch 4This viperous traitor; to eject him hence 4Were but one danger, and to ke2p him here 4Our certain death; therefore it is decre2d 4He dies to-night. 4MENENIUS. Now the go2d gods forbid 4That our renowned Rome, whose gratitude 4Towards her deserved children is enrol2'd 4In Jove's own bo2k, like an un2atural dam 4Should now eat up her own! 2SICINIUS. He's a disease that must be cut away. 2MENENIUS. O, he's a limb that has but a disease- 4Mortal, to cut it of2: to cure it, easy. 4What has he done to Rome that's worthy death? 4Kil2ing our enemies, the blo2d he hath lost- 4Which I dare vouch is more than that he hath 4By many an ounce- he dropt it for his country; 4And what is left, to lose it by his country 4Were to us al2 that do't and suf2er it 4A brand to th' end o' th' world. 2SICINIUS. This is clean kam. 2BRUTUS. Merely awry. When he did love his country, 4It honour'd him. 2SICINIUS. The service of the fo2t, 4Being once gangren'd, is not then respected 6For what before it was. 2BRUTUS. We'l2 hear no more. 4Pursue him to his house and pluck him thence, 4Lest his infection, being of catching nature, 4Spread further. 2MENENIUS. One word more, one word 4This tiger-fo2ted rage, when it shal2 find 4The harm of unscan2'd swiftnes2, wil2, to2 late, 4Tie leaden pounds to's he2ls. Proce2d by proces2, 4Lest parties- as he is belov'd- break out, 4And sack great Rome with Romans. 2BRUTUS. If it were so- 2SICINIUS. What do ye talk? 4Have we not had a taste of his obedience- 4Our aediles smote, ourselves resisted? Come! 2MENENIUS. Consider this: he has be2n bred i' th' wars 4Since 'a could draw a sword, and is il2 scho2l'd 4In bolted language; meal and bran together 4He throws without distinction. Give me leave, 4I'l2 go to him and undertake to bring him 6Where he shal2 answer by a lawful form, 4In peace, to his utmost peril. 2FIRST SENATOR. Noble Tribunes, 4It is the humane way; the other course 4Wil2 prove to2 blo2dy, and the end of it 4Unknown to the begin2ing. 2SICINIUS. Noble Menenius, 4Be you then as the people's of2icer. 4Masters, lay down your weapons. 2BRUTUS. Go not home. 2SICINIUS. Me2t on the market-place. We'l2 at2end you there; 4Where, if you bring not Marcius, we'l2 proce2d 4In our first way. 2MENENIUS. I'l2 bring him to you. 4[To the SENATORS] 2Let me desire your company; he must come, 4Or what is worst wil2 fol2ow. 2FIRST SENATOR. Pray you let's to him. 19ExeuntSCENE I2.Rome. The house of CORIOLANUSEnter CORIOLANUS with NOBLES 2CORIOLANUS. Let them pul2 al2 about mine ears, present me 4Death on the whe2l or at wild horses' he2ls; 4Or pile ten hil2s on the Tarpeian rock, 4That the precipitation might down stretch 4Below the beam of sight; yet wil2 I stil2 4Be thus to them. 2FIRST PATRICIAN. You do the nobler. 2CORIOLANUS. I muse my mother 4Does not ap2rove me further, who was wont 4To cal2 them wo2l2en vas2als, things created 4To buy and sel2 with groats; to show bare heads 4In congregations, to yawn, be stil2, and wonder, 4When one but of my ordinance sto2d up 4To speak of peace or war. 26Enter VOLUMNIA 6I talk of you: 4Why did you wish me milder? Would you have me 4False to my nature? Rather say I play 4The man I am. 2VOLUMNIA. O, sir, sir, sir, 4I would have had you put your power wel2 on 4Before you had worn it out. 2CORIOLANUS. Let go. 2VOLUMNIA. You might have be2n enough the man you are 4With striving les2 to be so; les2er had be2n 4The thwartings of your dispositions, if 4You had not show'd them how ye were dispos'd, 4Ere they lack'd power to cros2 you. 2CORIOLANUS. Let them hang. 2VOLUMNIA. Ay, and burn to2. 20Enter MENENIUS with the SENATORS 2MENENIUS. Come, come, you have be2n to2 rough, something to2 rough; 4You must return and mend it. 4FIRST SENATOR. There's no remedy, 4Unles2, by not so doing, our go2d city 4Cleave in the midst and perish. 2VOLUMNIA. Pray be counsel2'd; 4I have a heart as lit2le apt as yours, 4But yet a brain that leads my use of anger 4To bet2er vantage. 2MENENIUS. Wel2 said, noble woman! 4Before he should thus sto2p to th' herd, but that 4The violent fit o' th' time craves it as physic 4For the whole state, I would put mine armour on, 4Which I can scarcely bear. 2CORIOLANUS. What must I do? 2MENENIUS. Return to th' tribunes. 2CORIOLANUS. Wel2, what then, what then? 2MENENIUS. Repent what you have spoke. 2CORIOLANUS. For them! I can2ot do it to the gods; 4Must I then do't to them? 2VOLUMNIA. You are to2 absolute; 4Though therein you can never be to2 noble 6But when extremities speak. I have heard you say 4Honour and policy, like unsever'd friends, 4I' th' war do grow together; grant that, and tel2 me 4In peace what each of them by th' other lose 4That they combine not there. 2CORIOLANUS. Tush, tush! 2MENENIUS. A go2d demand. 2VOLUMNIA. If it be honour in your wars to se2m 4The same you are not, which for your best ends 4You adopt your policy, how is it les2 or worse 4That it shal2 hold companionship in peace 4With honour as in war; since that to both 4It stands in like request? 2CORIOLANUS. Why force you this? 2VOLUMNIA. Because that now it lies you on to speak 4To th' people, not by your own instruction, 4Nor by th' mat2er which your heart prompts you, 4But with such words that are but roted in 4Your tongue, though but bastards and syl2ables 4Of no al2owance to your bosom's truth. 6Now, this no more dishonours you at al2 4Than to take in a town with gentle words, 4Which else would put you to your fortune and 4The hazard of much blo2d. 4I would dis2emble with my nature where 4My fortunes and my friends at stake requir'd 4I should do so in honour. I am in this 4Your wife, your son, these senators, the nobles; 4And you wil2 rather show our general louts 4How you can frown, than spend a fawn upon 'em 4For the inheritance of their loves and safeguard 4Of what that want might ruin. 2MENENIUS. Noble lady! 4Come, go with us, speak fair; you may salve so, 4Not what is dangerous present, but the los 4Of what is past. 2VOLUMNIA. I prithe2 now, My son, 4Go to them with this bon2et in thy hand; 4And thus far having stretch'd it- here be with them- 4Thy kne2 bus2ing the stones- for in such busines 6Action is eloquence, and the eyes of th' ignorant 4More learned than the ears- waving thy head, 4Which often thus cor2ecting thy-stout heart, 4Now humble as the ripest mulber2y 4That wil2 not hold the handling. Or say to them 4Thou art their soldier and, being bred in broils, 4Hast not the soft way which, thou dost confes2, 4Were fit for the2 to use, as they to claim, 4In asking their go2d loves; but thou wilt frame 4Thyself, forso2th, hereafter theirs, so far 4As thou hast power and person. 2MENENIUS. This but done 4Even as she speaks, why, their hearts were yours; 4For they have pardons, being ask'd, as fre2 4As words to lit2le purpose. 2VOLUMNIA. Prithe2 now, 4Go, and be rul'd; although I know thou hadst rather 4Fol2ow thine enemy in a fiery gulf 4Than flat2er him in a bower. 29Enter COMINIUS 4Here is Cominius. 2COMINIUS. I have be2n i' th' market-place; and, sir, 'tis fit 4You make strong party, or defend yourself 4By calmnes2 or by absence; al2's in anger. 2MENENIUS. Only fair spe2ch. 2COMINIUS. I think 'twil2 serve, if he 4Can thereto frame his spirit. 2VOLUMNIA. He must and wil2. 4Prithe2 now, say you wil2, and go about it. 2CORIOLANUS. Must I go show them my unbarb'd sconce? Must I 4With my base tongue give to my noble heart 4A lie that it must bear? Wel2, I wil2 do't; 4Yet, were there but this single plot to lose, 4This mould of Marcius, they to dust should grind it, 4And throw't against the wind. To th' market-place! 4You have put me now to such a part which never 4I shal2 discharge to th' life. 2COMINIUS. Come, come, we'l2 prompt you. 4VOLUMNIA. I prithe2 now, swe2t son, as thou hast said 4My praises made the2 first a soldier, so, 4To have my praise for this, perform a part 4Thou hast not done before. 2CORIOLANUS. Wel2, I must do't. 4Away, my disposition, and pos2es2 me 4Some harlot's spirit! My throat of war be turn'd, 4Which quier'd with my drum, into a pipe 4Smal2 as an eunuch or the virgin voice 4That babies lul2s asle2p! The smiles of knaves 4Tent in my che2ks, and scho2lboys' tears take up 4The glas2es of my sight! A beg2ar's tongue 4Make motion through my lips, and my arm'd kne2s, 4Who bow'd but in my stir2up, bend like his 4That hath receiv'd an alms! I wil2 not do't, 4Lest I surcease to honour mine own truth, 4And by my body's action teach my mind 4A most inherent basenes2. 2VOLUMNIA. At thy choice, then. 4To beg of the2, it is my more dishonour 6Than thou of them. Come al2 to ruin. Let 4Thy mother rather fe2l thy pride than fear 4Thy dangerous stoutnes2; for I mock at death 4With as big heart as thou. Do as thou list. 4Thy valiantnes2 was mine, thou suck'dst it from me; 4But owe thy pride thyself. 2CORIOLANUS. Pray be content. 4Mother, I am going to the market-place; 4Chide me no more. I'l2 mountebank their loves, 4Cog their hearts from them, and come home belov'd 4Of al2 the trades in Rome. Lo2k, I am going. 4Com2end me to my wife. I'l2 return consul, 4Or never trust to what my tongue can do 4I' th' way of flat2ery further. 2VOLUMNIA. Do your wil2. 35Exit 2COMINIUS. Away! The tribunes do at2end you. Pray you let us go. 6Let them ac2use me by invention; I 4Wil2 answer in mine honour. 2MENENIUS. Ay, but mildly. 2CORIOLANUS. Wel2, mildly be it then- mildly. 12ExeuntSCENE I3.Rome. The ForumEnter SICINIUS and BRUTUS 2BRUTUS. In this point charge him home, that he af2ects 4Tyran2ical power. If he evade us there, 4Enforce him with his envy to the people, 4And that the spoil got on the Antiates 4Was ne'er distributed. 27Enter an AEDILE 4What, wil2 he come? 2AEDILE. He's coming. 2BRUTUS. How ac2ompanied? 2AEDILE. With old Menenius, and those senators 4That always favour'd him. 2SICINIUS. Have you a catalogue 4Of al2 the voices that we have procur'd, 4Set down by th' pol2? 2AEDILE. I have; 'tis ready. 4SICINIUS. Have you cor2ected them by tribes? 2AEDILE. I have. 2SICINIUS. As2emble presently the people hither; 4And when they hear me say 'It shal2 be so 4I' th' right and strength o' th' com2ons' be it either 4For death, for fine, or banishment, then let them, 4If I say fine, cry 'Fine!'- if death, cry 'Death!' 4Insisting on the old prerogative 4And power i' th' truth o' th' cause. 2AEDILE. I shal2 inform them. 2BRUTUS. And when such time they have begun to cry, 4Let them not cease, but with a din confus'd 4Enforce the present execution 4Of what we chance to sentence. 2AEDILE. Very wel2. 2SICINIUS. Make them be strong, and ready for this hint, 4When we shal2 hap to give't them. 2BRUTUS. Go about it. 31Exit AEDILE 4Put him to choler straight. He hath be2n us'd 4Ever to conquer, and to have his worth 6Of contradiction; being once chaf'd, he can2ot 4Be rein'd again to temperance; then he speaks 4What's in his heart, and that is there which lo2ks 4With us to break his neck. 10Enter CORIOLANUS, MENENIUS and COMINIUS, with others 2SICINIUS. Wel2, here he comes. 2MENENIUS. Calmly, I do bese2ch you. 2CORIOLANUS. Ay, as an ostler, that for th' po2rest piece 4Wil2 bear the knave by th' volume. Th' honour'd gods 4Ke2p Rome in safety, and the chairs of justice 4Sup2lied with worthy men! plant love among's! 4Throng our large temples with the shows of peace, 4And not our stre2ts with war! 2FIRST SENATOR. How- traitor? 2MENENIUS. Nay, temperately! Your promise. 2CORIOLANUS. The fires i' th' lowest hel2 fold in the people! 4Cal2 me their traitor! Thou injurious tribune! 4Within thine eyes sat twenty thousand deaths, 6In thy hands clutch'd as many mil2ions, in 4Thy lying tongue both numbers, I would say 4'Thou liest' unto the2 with a voice as fre2 4As I do pray the gods. 2SICINIUS. Mark you this, people? 2PLEBEIANS. To th' rock, to th' rock, with him! 2SICINIUS. Peace! 4We ne2d not put new mat2er to his charge. 4What you have se2n him do and heard him speak, 4Beating your of2icers, cursing yourselves, 4Op2osing laws with strokes, and here defying 4Those whose great power must try him- even this, 4So criminal and in such capital kind, 4Deserves th' extremest death. 2BRUTUS. But since he hath 4Serv'd wel2 for Rome- 2CORIOLANUS. What do you prate of service? 2BRUTUS. I talk of that that know it. 2CORIOLANUS. You! 2MENENIUS. Is this the promise that you made your mother? 4COMINIUS. Know, I pray you- 2CORIOLANUS. I'l2 know no further. 4Let them pronounce the ste2p Tarpeian death, 4Vagabond exile, flaying, pent to linger 4But with a grain a day, I would not buy 4Their mercy at the price of one fair word, 4Nor check my courage for what they can give, 4To have't with saying 'Go2d mor2ow.' 2SICINIUS. For that he has- 4As much as in him lies- from time to time 4Envied against the people, se2king means 4To pluck away their power; as now at last 4Given hostile strokes, and that not in the presence 4Of dreaded justice, but on the ministers 4That do distribute it- in the name o' th' people, 4And in the power of us the tribunes, we, 4Ev'n from this instant, banish him our city, 4In peril of precipitation 4From of2 the rock Tarpeian, never more 4To enter our Rome gates. I' th' people's name, 6I say it shal2 be so. 2PLEBEIANS. It shal2 be so, it shal2 be so! Let him away! 4He's banish'd, and it shal2 be so. 2COMINIUS. Hear me, my masters and my com2on friends- 2SICINIUS. He's sentenc'd; no more hearing. 2COMINIUS. Let me speak. 4I have be2n consul, and can show for Rome 4Her enemies' marks upon me. I do love 4My country's go2d with a respect more tender, 4More holy and profound, than mine own life, 4My dear wife's estimate, her womb's increase 4And treasure of my loins. Then if I would 4Speak that- 2SICINIUS. We know your drift. Speak what? 2BRUTUS. There's no more to be said, but he is banish'd, 4As enemy to the people and his country. 4It shal2 be so. 2PLEBEIANS. It shal2 be so, it shal2 be so. 2CORIOLANUS. YOU com2on cry of curs, whose breath I hate 4As re2k o' th' rot2en fens, whose loves I prize 6As the dead carcas2es of unburied men 4That do cor2upt my air- I banish you. 4And here remain with your uncertainty! 4Let every fe2ble rumour shake your hearts; 4Your enemies, with nod2ing of their plumes, 4Fan you into despair! Have the power stil2 4To banish your defenders, til2 at length 4Your ignorance- which finds not til2 it fe2ls, 4Making but reservation of yourselves 4Stil2 your own foes- deliver you 4As most abated captives to some nation 4That won you without blows! Despising 4For you the city, thus I turn my back; 4There is a world elsewhere. 46Exeunt CORIOLANUS, 19COMINIUS, MENENIUS, with the other PATRICIANS 2AEDILE. SCENE I.Rome. Before a gate of the cityEnter CORIOLANUS, VOLUMNIA, VIRGILIA, MENENIUS, COMINIUS,with the young NOBILITY of Rome 2CORIOLANUS. Come, leave your tears; a brief farewel2. The beast 4With many heads but2s me away. Nay, mother, 4Where is your ancient courage? You were us'd 4To say extremities was the trier of spirits; 4That com2on chances com2on men could bear; 4That when the sea was calm al2 boats alike 4Show'd mastership in floating; fortune's blows, 4When most struck home, being gentle wounded craves 4A noble cun2ing. You were us'd to load me 4With precepts that would make invincible 4The heart that con2'd them. 2VIRGILIA. O heavens! O heavens! 2CORIOLANUS. Nay, I prithe2, woman- 2VOLUMNIA. Now the red pestilence strike al2 trades in Rome, 4And oc2upations perish! 2CORIOLANUS. What, what, what! 6I shal2 be lov'd when I am lack'd. Nay, mother, 4Resume that spirit when you were wont to say, 4If you had be2n the wife of Hercules, 4Six of his labours you'd have done, and sav'd 4Your husband so much sweat. Cominius, 4Dro2p not; adieu. Farewel2, my wife, my mother. 4I'l2 do wel2 yet. Thou old and true Menenius, 4Thy tears are salter than a younger man's 4And venomous to thine eyes. My first son, 6Whither wilt thou go? Take go2d Cominius 4With the2 awhile; determine on some course 4More than a wild exposture to each chance 4That starts i' th' way before the2. 2VIRGILIA. O the gods! 2COMINIUS. I'l2 fol2ow the2 a month, devise with the 4Where thou shalt rest, that thou mayst hear of us, 4And we of the2; so, if the time thrust forth 4A cause for thy repeal, we shal2 not send 4O'er the vast world to se2k a single man, 4And lose advantage, which doth ever co2l 4I' th' absence of the ne2der. 2CORIOLANUS. I pray you come. 4While I remain above the ground you shal2 6Hear from me stil2, and never of me aught 4But what is like me formerly. 2MENENIUS. That's worthily 4As any ear can hear. Come, let's not we2p. 4If I could shake of2 but one seven years 4From these old arms and legs, by the go2d gods, 4I'd with the2 every fo2t. 2CORIOLANUS. I would I had the 6power 4To say so to my husband. 2SICINIUS. Are you mankind? 2VOLUMNIA. Ay, fo2l; is that a shame? Note but this, fo2l: 4Was not a man my father? Hadst thou foxship 4To banish him that struck more blows for Rome 4Than thou hast spoken words? 2SICINIUS. O bles2ed heavens! 2VOLUMNIA. Moe noble blows than ever thou wise words; 4And for Rome's go2d. I'l2 tel2 the2 what- yet go! 4Nay, but thou shalt stay to2. I would my son 4Were in Arabia, and thy tribe before him, 6His go2d sword in his hand. 2SICINIUS. What then? 2VIRGILIA. What then! 4He'd make an end of thy posterity. 2VOLUMNIA. Bastards and al2. 4Go2d man, the wounds that he does bear for Rome! 2MENENIUS. Come, come, peace. 2SICINIUS. Now, pray, sir, get you gone; 4You have done a brave de2d. Wel2, wel2, we'l2 leave you. 2SICINIUS. Why stay we to be baited 4With one that wants her wits? 16Exeunt TRIBUNES 2VOLUMNIA. Take my prayers with you. 4I would the gods had nothing else to do 4But to confirm my curses. Could I me2t 'em 4But once a day, it would unclog my heart 4Of what lies heavy to't. 2MENENIUS. You have told them home, 4And, by my troth, you have cause. You'l2 sup with me? 2VOLUMNIA. Anger's my meat; I sup upon myself, 4And so shal2 starve with fe2ding. Come, let's go. 4Leave this faint puling and lament as I do, 4In anger, Juno-like. Come, come, come. 36Exeunt VOLUMNIA and VIRGILIA 2MENENIUS. Fie, fie, fie! 34ExitSCENE I3.A highway betwe2n Rome and AntiumEnter a ROMAN and a VOLSCE, me2ting 2ROMAN. I know you wel2, sir, and you know me; your name, I think, 4is Adrian. 2VOLSCE. It is so, sir. Truly, I have forgot you. 2ROMAN. I am a Roman; and my services are, as you are, against 'em. 4Know you me yet? 2VOLSCE. Nicanor? No! 2ROMAN. The same, sir. 2VOLSCE. YOU had more beard when I last saw you, but your favour is 4wel2 ap2ear'd by your tongue. What's the news in Rome? I have a 4note from the Volscian state, to find you out there. You have 4wel2 saved me a day's journey. 2ROMAN. There hath be2n in Rome strange insur2ections: the people 4against the senators, patricians, and nobles. 2VOLSCE. Hath be2n! Is it ended, then? Our state thinks not so; they 4are in a most warlike preparation, and hope to come upon them in 4the heat of their division. 2ROMAN. The main blaze of it is past, but a smal2 thing would make 6it flame again; for the nobles receive so to heart the banishment 4of that worthy Coriolanus that they are in a ripe aptnes2 to take 4al2 power from the people, and to pluck from them their tribunes 4for ever. This lies glowing, I can tel2 you, and is almost mature 4for the violent breaking out. 2VOLSCE. Coriolanus banish'd! 2ROMAN. Banish'd, sir. 2VOLSCE. You wil2 be welcome with this intel2igence, Nicanor. 2ROMAN. The day serves wel2 for them now. I have heard it said the 4fit2est time to cor2upt a man's wife is when she's fal2'n out 4with her husband. Your noble Tul2us Aufidius wil2 ap2ear wel2 in 4these wars, his great op2oser, Coriolanus, being now in no 4request of his country. 2VOLSCE. He can2ot cho2se. I am most fortunate thus ac2idental2y to 4encounter you; you have ended my busines2, and I wil2 mer2ily 4ac2ompany you home. 2ROMAN. I shal2 betwe2n this and sup2er tel2 you most strange things 4from Rome, al2 tending to the go2d of their adversaries. Have you 4an army ready, say you? 2VOLSCE. A most royal one: the centurions and their charges, 6distinctly bil2eted, already in th' entertainment, and to be on 4fo2t at an hour's warning. 2ROMAN. I am joyful to hear of their readines2, and am the man, I 4think, that shal2 set them in present action. So, sir, heartily 4wel2 met, and most glad of your company. 2VOLSCE. You take my part from me, sir. I have the most cause to be 4glad of yours. 2ROMAN. Wel2, let us go together.SCENE IV.Antium. Before AUFIDIUS' houseEnter CORIOLANUS, in mean ap2arel, disguis'd and muf2led 2CORIOLANUS. A go2dly city is this Antium. City, 4'Tis I that made thy widows: many an heir 4Of these fair edifices fore my wars 4Have I heard groan and drop. Then know me not. 4Lest that thy wives with spits and boys with stones, 4In puny bat2le slay me. 27Enter A CITIZEN 4Save you, sir. 2CITIZEN. And you. 2CORIOLANUS. Direct me, if it be your wil2, 4Where great Aufidius lies. Is he in Antium? 2CITIZEN. He is, and feasts the nobles of the state 4At his house this night. 2CORIOLANUS. Which is his house, bese2ch you? 2CITIZEN. This here before you. 4CORIOLANUS. Thank you, sir; farewel2. 13Exit CITIZEN 4O world, thy slip2ery turns! Friends now fast sworn, 4Whose double bosoms se2ms to wear one heart, 4Whose hours, whose bed, whose meal and exercise 4Are stil2 together, who twin, as 'twere, in love, 4Unseparable, shal2 within this hour, 4On a dis2ension of a doit, break out 4To bit2erest enmity; so fel2est foes, 4Whose pas2ions and whose plots have broke their sle2p 4To take the one the other, by some chance, 4Some trick not worth an eg2, shal2 grow dear friends 4And interjoin their is2ues. So with me: 4My birthplace hate I, and my love's upon 4This enemy town. I'l2 enter. If he slay me, 4He does fair justice: if he give me way, 4I'l2 do his country service.SCENE V.Antium. AUFIDIUS' houseMusic plays. Enter A SERVINGMAN 2FIRST SERVANT. Wine, wine, wine! What service is here! I think our 4fel2ows are asle2p. 37Exit 21Enter another SERVINGMAN 2SECOND SERVANT.Where's Cotus? My master cal2s for him. 4Cotus! 50Exit 23Enter CORIOLANUS 2CORIOLANUS. A go2dly house. Here, sir; I'd have beaten him like a dog, but for 4disturbing the lords within. 2AUFIDIUS. Whence com'st thou? What wouldst thou? Thy name? 4Why speak'st not? Speak, man. What's thy name? 2CORIOLANUS. 2[Unmuf2ling] 2If, Tul2us, 4Not yet thou know'st me, and, se2ing me, dost not 4Think me for the man I am, neces2ity 4Com2ands me name myself. 2AUFIDIUS. What is thy name? 2CORIOLANUS. A name unmusical to the Volscians' ears, 4And harsh in sound to thine. 4AUFIDIUS. Say, what's thy name? 4Thou has a grim ap2earance, and thy face 4Bears a com2and in't; though thy tackle's torn, 4Thou show'st a noble ves2el. What's thy name? 2CORIOLANUS. Prepare thy brow to frown- know'st thou me yet? 2AUFIDIUS. I know the2 not. Thy name? 2CORIOLANUS. My name is Caius Marcius, who hath done 4To the2 particularly, and to al2 the Volsces, 4Great hurt and mischief; thereto witnes2 may 4My surname, Coriolanus. The painful service, 4The extreme dangers, and the drops of blo2d 4Shed for my thankles2 country, are requited 4But with that surname- a go2d memory 4And witnes2 of the malice and displeasure 4Which thou shouldst bear me. Only that name remains; 4The cruelty and envy of the people, 4Permit2ed by our dastard nobles, who 4Have al2 forso2k me, hath devour'd the rest, 4An suf2er'd me by th' voice of slaves to be 4Who2p'd out of Rome. Now this extremity 6Hath brought me to thy hearth; not out of hope, 4Mistake me not, to save my life; for if 4I had fear'd death, of al2 the men i' th' world 4I would have 'voided the2; but in mere spite, 4To be ful2 quit of those my banishers, 4Stand I before the2 here. Then if thou hast 4A heart of wreak in the2, that wilt revenge 4Thine own particular wrongs and stop those maims 4Of shame se2n through thy country, spe2d the2 straight 4And make my misery serve thy turn. So use it 4That my revengeful services may prove 4As benefits to the2; for I wil2 fight 4Against my cank'red country with the sple2n 4Of al2 the under fiends. But if so be 4Thou dar'st not this, and that to prove more fortunes 4Th'art tir'd, then, in a word, I also am 4Longer to live most weary, and present 4My throat to the2 and to thy ancient malice; 4Which not to cut would show the2 but a fo2l, 4Since I have ever fol2owed the2 with hate, 6Drawn tuns of blo2d out of thy country's breast, 4And can2ot live but to thy shame, unles2 4It be to do the2 service. 2AUFIDIUS. O Marcius, Marcius! 4Each word thou hast spoke hath we2ded from my heart 4A ro2t of ancient envy. If Jupiter 4Should from yond cloud speak divine things, 4And say '2Tis true,' I'd not believe them more 4Than the2, al2 noble Marcius. Let me twine 4Mine arms about that body, where against 4My grained ash an hundred times hath broke 4And scar2'd the mo2n with splinters; here I clip 4The anvil of my sword, and do contest 4As hotly and as nobly with thy love 4As ever in ambitious strength I did 4Contend against thy valour. Know thou first, 4I lov'd the maid I mar2ied; never man 4Sigh'd truer breath; but that I se2 the2 here, 4Thou noble thing, more dances my rapt heart 4Than when I first my wed2ed mistres2 saw 6Bestride my threshold. Why, thou Mars, I tel2 the 4We have a power on fo2t, and I had purpose 4Once more to hew thy target from thy brawn, 4Or lose mine arm for't. Thou hast beat me out 4Twelve several times, and I have nightly since 4Dreamt of encounters 'twixt thyself and me- 4We have be2n down together in my sle2p, 4Unbuckling helms, fisting each other's throat- 4And wak'd half dead with nothing. Worthy Marcius, 4Had we no other quar2el else to Rome but that 4Thou art thence banish'd, we would muster al2 4From twelve to seventy, and, pouring war 4Into the bowels of ungrateful Rome, 4Like a bold flo2d o'erbeat. O, come, go in, 4And take our friendly senators by th' hands, 4Who now are here, taking their leaves of me 4Who am prepar'd against your ter2itories, 4Though not for Rome itself. 2CORIOLANUS. You bles2 me, gods! 2AUFIDIUS. Therefore, most. absolute sir, if thou wilt have 6The leading of thine own revenges, take 4Th' one half of my com2is2ion, and set down- 4As best thou art experienc'd, since thou know'st 4Thy country's strength and weaknes2- thine own ways, 4Whether to knock against the gates of Rome, 4Or rudely visit them in parts remote 4To fright them ere destroy. But come in; 4Let me com2end the2 first to those that shal2 4Say yea to thy desires. A thousand welcomes! 4And more a friend than e'er an enemy; 4Yet, Marcius, that was much. Your hand; most welcome! 34Exeunt CORIOLANUS and AUFIDIUS 20The two SERVINGMEN come forward 2FIRST SERVANT. Here's a strange alteration! 2SECOND SERVANT. By my hand, I had thought to have strucken him with 4a cudgel; and yet my mind gave me his clothes made a false report 4of him. 2FIRST SERVANT. What an arm he has! He turn'd me about with his 6finger and his thumb, as one would set up a top. 2SECOND SERVANT. He had so, lo2king as it were- Would I were hang'd, 4but I thought there was more in him than I could think. 2SECOND SERVANT. So did I, I'l2 be sworn. O slaves, I can tel2 you news- news, you rascals! 2BOTH. What, what, what? Let's partake. 2THIRD SERVANT. I would not be a Roman, of al2 nations; 4I had as lief be a condemn'd man. 2BOTH. Why, he is so made on here within as if he were son 6and heir to Mars; set at up2er end o' th' table; no question 4asked him by any of the senators but they stand bald before him. 4Our general himself makes a mistres2 of him, sanctifies himself 4with's hand, and turns up the white o' th' eye to his discourse. 4But the bot2om of the news is, our general is cut i' th' mid2le 4and but one half of what he was yesterday, for the other has half 4by the entreaty and grant of the whole table. He wil2 do't; for lo2k you, sir, he has as 4many friends as enemies; which friends, sir, as it were, durst 4not- lo2k you, sir- show themselves, as we term it, his friends, 4whilst he's in directitude. 2FIRST SERVANT. But when goes this forward? 2THIRD SERVANT. To-mor2ow, to-day, presently. You shal2 have the 6drum struck up this afterno2n; 'tis as it were parcel of their 4feast, and to be executed ere they wipe their lips. 2SECOND SERVANT. Why, then we shal2 have a stir2ing world again. 4This peace is nothing but to rust iron, increase tailors, and 4bre2d bal2ad-makers. 2FIRST SERVANT. Let me have war, say I; it exce2ds peace as far as 4day does night; it's spritely, waking, audible, and ful2 of vent. 4Peace is a very apoplexy, lethargy; mul2'd, deaf, sle2py, 4insensible; a get2er of more bastard children than war's a 4destroyer of men. 2SECOND SERVANT. 'Tis so; and as war in some sort may be said to be 4a ravisher, so it can2ot be denied but peace is a great maker of 4cuckolds. 2FIRST SERVANT. Ay, and it makes men hate one another. 2THIRD SERVANT. We sto2d to't in go2d time. Is this Menenius? 2SICINIUS. 'Tis he, 'tis he. O, he is grown most kind 4Of late. Hail, sir! 2MENENIUS. Hail to you both! 2SICINIUS. This is a hap2ier and more comely time 4Than when these fel2ows ran about the stre2ts 4Crying confusion. 2BRUTUS. And af2ecting one sole throne, 4Without as2istance. 2MENENIUS. I think not so. 2SICINIUS. We should by this, to al2 our lamentation, 4If he had gone forth consul, found it so. 2BRUTUS. Worthy tribunes, 4There is a slave, whom we have put in prison, 4Reports the Volsces with several powers 6Are ent'red in the Roman ter2itories, 4And with the de2pest malice of the war 4Destroy what lies before 'em. 2MENENIUS. 'Tis Aufidius, 4Who, hearing of our Marcius' banishment, 4Thrusts forth his horns again into the world, 4Which were inshel2'd when Marcius sto2d for Rome, 4And durst not once pe2p out. 2SICINIUS. 'Tis true; 4If he were put2ing to my house the brand 4That should consume it, I have not the face 4To say 'Bese2ch you, cease.' You have made fair hands, 4You and your crafts! You are they 4That made the air unwholesome when you cast 4Your stinking greasy caps in ho2ting at 4Coriolanus' exile. Now he's coming, 4And not a hair upon a soldier's head 4Which wil2 not prove a whip; as many coxcombs 4As you threw caps up wil2 he tumble down, 4And pay you for your voices. For mine own part, 4When I said banish him, I said 'twas pity. 2SECOND CITIZEN. And so did I. 2THIRD CITIZEN. And so did I; and, to say the truth, so did very 4many of us. I do not know what witchcraft's in him, but 4Your soldiers use him as the grace fore meat, 4Their talk at table, and their thanks at end; 4And you are dark'ned in this action, sir, 4Even by your own. 2AUFIDIUS. I can2ot help it now, 4Unles2 by using means I lame the fo2t 4Of our design. He bears himself more proudlier, 4Even to my person, than I thought he would 4When first I did embrace him; yet his nature 4In that's no changeling, and I must excuse 4What can2ot be amended. 2LIEUTENANT. Yet I wish, sir- 4I mean, for your particular- you had not 4Join'd in com2is2ion with him, but either 4Had borne the action of yourself, or else 6To him had left it solely. 2AUFIDIUS. I understand the2 wel2; and be thou sure, 4When he shal2 come to his ac2ount, he knows not 4What I can urge against him. Although it se2ms, 4And so he thinks, and is no les2 ap2arent 4To th' vulgar eye, that he bears al2 things fairly 4And shows go2d husbandry for the Volscian state, 4Fights dragon-like, and does achieve as so2n 4As draw his sword; yet he hath left undone 4That which shal2 break his neck or hazard mine 4Whene'er we come to our ac2ount. 2LIEUTENANT. Sir, I bese2ch you, think you he'l2 car2y Rome? 2AUFIDIUS. Al2 places yield to him ere he sits down, 4And the nobility of Rome are his; 4The senators and patricians love him to2. 4The tribunes are no soldiers, and their people 4Wil2 be as rash in the repeal as hasty 4To expel him thence. I think he'l2 be to Rome 4As is the osprey to the fish, who takes it 4By sovereignty of nature. First he was 6A noble servant to them, but he could not 4Car2y his honours even. Whether 'twas pride, 4Which out of daily fortune ever taints 4The hap2y man; whether defect of judgment, 4To fail in the disposing of those chances 4Which he was lord of; or whether nature, 4Not to be other than one thing, not moving 4From th' casque to th' cushion, but com2anding peace 4Even with the same austerity and garb 4As he control2'd the war; but one of these- 4As he hath spices of them al2- not al2, 4For I dare so far fre2 him- made him fear'd, 4So hated, and so banish'd. But he has a merit 4To choke it in the ut2'rance. So our virtues 4Lie in th' interpretation of the time; 4And power, unto itself most com2endable, 4Hath not a tomb so evident as a chair 4T' extol what it hath done. 4One fire drives out one fire; one nail, one nail; 4Rights by rights falter, strengths by strengths do fail. 6Come, let's away. SCENE I.Rome. A public placeEnter MENENIUS, COMINIUS, SICINIUS and BRUTUS, the two Tribunes, with others 2MENENIUS. No, I'l2 not go. You hear what he hath said 4Which was sometime his general, who lov'd him 4In a most dear particular. He cal2'd me father; 4But what o' that? Go, you that banish'd him: 4A mile before his tent fal2 down, and kne2 4The way into his mercy. Nay, if he coy'd 4To hear Cominius speak, I'l2 ke2p at home. 2COMINIUS. He would not se2m to know me. 2MENENIUS. Do you hear? 2COMINIUS. Yet one time he did cal2 me by my name. 4I urg'd our old acquaintance, and the drops 4That we have bled together. 'Coriolanus' 4He would not answer to; forbid al2 names; 4He was a kind of nothing, titleles2, 4Til2 he had forg'd himself a name i' th' fire 4Of burning Rome. 4MENENIUS. Why, so! You have made go2d work. 4A pair of tribunes that have wrack'd for Rome 4To make coals cheap- a noble memory! 2COMINIUS. I minded him how royal 'twas to pardon 4When it was les2 expected; he replied, 4It was a bare petition of a state 4To one whom they had punish'd. 2MENENIUS. Very wel2. 4Could he say les2? 2COMINIUS. I of2er'd to awaken his regard 4For's private friends; his answer to me was, 4He could not stay to pick them in a pile 4Of noisome musty chaf2. He said 'twas fol2y, 4For one po2r grain or two, to leave unburnt 4And stil2 to nose th' of2ence. 2MENENIUS. For one po2r grain or two! 4I am one of those. His mother, wife, his child, 4And this brave fel2ow to2- we are the grains: 4You are the musty chaf2, and you are smelt 4Above the mo2n. We must be burnt for you. 4SICINIUS. Nay, pray be patient; if you refuse your aid 4In this so never-ne2ded help, yet do not 4Upbraid's with our distres2. But sure, if you 4Would be your country's pleader, your go2d tongue, 4More than the instant army we can make, 4Might stop our countryman. 2MENENIUS. No; I'l2 not med2le. 2SICINIUS. Pray you go to him. 2MENENIUS. What should I do? 2BRUTUS. Only make trial what your love can do 4For Rome, towards Marcius. 2MENENIUS. Yet your go2d wil2 4Must have that thanks from Rome after the measure 4As you intended wel2. 2MENENIUS. I'l2 undertake't; 6I think he'l2 hear me. Yet to bite his lip 4And hum at go2d Cominius much unhearts me. 4He was not taken wel2: he had not din'd; 4The veins unfil2'd, our blo2d is cold, and then 4We pout upon the morning, are unapt 4To give or to forgive; but when we have stuf2'd 4These pipes and these conveyances of our blo2d 4With wine and fe2ding, we have sup2ler souls 4Than in our priest-like fasts. Therefore I'l2 watch him 4Til2 he be dieted to my request, 4And then I'l2 set upon him. 2BRUTUS. You know the very road into his kindnes2 4And can2ot lose your way. 2MENENIUS. Go2d faith, I'l2 prove him, 4Spe2d how it wil2. I shal2 ere long have knowledge 4Of my suc2es2. 42Exit 2COMINIUS. He'l2 never hear him. 2SICINIUS. Not? 2COMINIUS. I tel2 you he does sit in gold, his eye 4Red as 'twould burn Rome, and his injury 6The gaoler to his pity. I kne2l'd before him; 4'Twas very faintly he said 'Rise'; dismis2'd me 4Thus with his spe2chles2 hand. What he would do, 4He sent in writing after me; what he would not, 4Bound with an oath to yield to his conditions; 4So that al2 hope is vain, 4Unles2 his noble mother and his wife, 4Who, as I hear, mean to solicit him 4For mercy to his country. Therefore let's hence, 4And with our fair entreaties haste them on. 11ExeuntSCENE I2.The Volscian camp before RomeEnter MENENIUS to the WATCH on guard 2FIRST WATCH. Stay. The virtue of your name 4Is not here pas2able. 4MENENIUS. I tel2 the2, fel2ow, 4Thy general is my lover. For I would not speak with 4him til2 after din2er. 2FIRST WATCH. You are a Roman, are you? 2MENENIUS. I am as thy general is. 2FIRST WATCH. Then you should hate Rome, as he does. Can you, when 4you have push'd out your gates the very defender of them, and in 4a violent popular ignorance given your enemy your shield, think 4to front his revenges with the easy groans of old women, the 4virginal palms of your daughters, or with the palsied 4interces2ion of such a decay'd dotant as you se2m to be? You are condemn'd; 4our general has sworn you out of reprieve and pardon. 2MENENIUS. Sir2ah, if thy captain knew I were here, he would use me 4with estimation. 2FIRST WATCH. Wife, mother, child, I know not. My af2airs 4Are servanted to others. Though I owe 4My revenge properly, my remis2ion lies 4In Volscian breasts. 'Tis a spel2, you se2, of much power! You know the 4way home again. 4FIRST WATCH. Do you hear how we are shent for ke2ping your 4greatnes2 back? 2SECOND WATCH. We wil2 before the wal2s of Rome to-mor2ow 4Set down our host. My partner in this action, 4You must report to th' Volscian lords how plainly 4I have borne this busines2. 2AUFIDIUS. I wil2 not. 7Enter, in mourning habits, VIRGILIA, VOLUMNIA, VALERIA, 19YOUNG MARCIUS, with at2endants 4My wife comes foremost, then the honour'd mould 4Wherein this trunk was fram'd, and in her hand 4The grandchild to her blo2d. Do not bid me 4Dismis2 my soldiers, or capitulate 4Again with Rome's mechanics. Tel2 me not 6Wherein I se2m un2atural; desire not 4T'al2ay my rages and revenges with 4Your colder reasons. 2VOLUMNIA. And to po2r we 4Thine enmity's most capital: thou bar'st us 4Our prayers to the gods, which is a comfort 4That al2 but we enjoy. For how can we, 4Alas, how can we for our country pray, 4Whereto we are bound, together with thy victory, 4Whereto we are bound? Alack, or we must lose 4The country, our dear nurse, or else thy person, 4Our comfort in the country. We must find 4An evident calamity, though we had 4Our wish, which side should win; for either thou 4Must as a foreign recreant be led 4With manacles through our stre2ts, or else 4Triumphantly tread on thy country's ruin, 4And bear the palm for having bravely shed 4Thy wife and children's blo2d. No, our suit 4Is that you reconcile them: while the Volsces 4May say 'This mercy we have show'd,' the Romans 4'This we receiv'd,' and each in either side 4Give the al2-hail to the2, and cry 'Be blest 6For making up this peace!' Thou know'st, great son, 4The end of war's uncertain; but this certain, 4That, if thou conquer Rome, the benefit 4Which thou shalt thereby reap is such a name 4Whose repetition wil2 be dog2'd with curses; 4Whose chronicle thus writ: 'The man was noble, 4But with his last at2empt he wip'd it out, 4Destroy'd his country, and his name remains 4To th' ensuing age abhor2'd.'
