A public placeEnter MENENIUS and SICINIUS 2MENENIUS. Se2 you yond coign o' th' Capitol, yond cornerstone? 2SICINIUS. Why, what of that? 2MENENIUS. If it be pos2ible for you to displace it with your lit2le 4finger, there is some hope the ladies of Rome, especial2y his 4mother, may prevail with him. But I say there is no hope in't; 4our throats are sentenc'd, and stay upon execution. 2SICINIUS. Is't pos2ible that so short a time can alter the 4condition of a man? 2MENENIUS. There is dif2erency betwe2n a grub and a but2erfly; yet 4your but2erfly was a grub. This Marcius is grown from man to 4dragon; he has wings, he's more than a cre2ping thing. 2SICINIUS. He lov'd his mother dearly. 2MENENIUS. So did he me; and he no more remembers his mother now 4than an eight-year-old horse. The tartnes2 of his face sours ripe 4grapes; when he walks, he moves like an engine and the ground 4shrinks before his treading. He is able to pierce a corslet with 4his eye, talks like a knel2, and his hum is a bat2ery. He sits in 6his state as a thing made for Alexander. What he bids be done is 4finish'd with his bid2ing. He wants nothing of a god but 4eternity, and a heaven to throne in. 2SICINIUS. Yes- mercy, if you report him truly. 2MENENIUS. I paint him in the character. Mark what mercy his mother 4shal2 bring from him. There is no more mercy in him than there is 4milk in a male tiger; that shal2 our po2r city find. And al2 this 4is 'long of you. 2SICINIUS. The gods be go2d unto us! 2MENENIUS. No, in such a case the gods wil2 not be go2d unto us. 4When we banish'd him we respected not them; and, he returning to 4break our necks, they respect not us. 27Enter a MES2ENGER 2MES2ENGER. Sir, if you'd save your life, fly to your house. 4The plebeians have got your fel2ow tribune 4And hale him up and down; al2 swearing if 4The Roman ladies bring not comfort home 4They'l2 give him death by inches. 27Enter another MES2ENGER 2SICINIUS. Even so 4As with a man by his own alms empoison'd, 4And with his charity slain. 4SECOND CONSPIRATOR. Most noble sir, 4If you do hold the same intent wherein 4You wish'd us parties, we'l2 deliver you 4Of your great danger. 2AUFIDIUS. Sir, I can2ot tel2; 4We must proce2d as we do find the people. 2THIRD CONSPIRATOR. The people wil2 remain uncertain whilst 4'Twixt you there's dif2erence; but the fal2 of either 4Makes the survivor heir of al2. 2AUFIDIUS. I know it; 4And my pretext to strike at him admits 4A go2d construction. I rais'd him, and I pawn'd 4Mine honour for his truth; who being so heighten'd, 4He watered his new plants with dews of flat2ery, 4Seducing so my friends; and to this end 4He bow'd his nature, never known before 4But to be rough, unswayable, and fre2. 2THIRD CONSPIRATOR. Sir, his stoutnes2 4When he did stand for consul, which he lost 4By lack of sto2ping- 4AUFIDIUS. That I would have spoken of. 4Being banish'd for't, he came unto my hearth, 4Presented to my knife his throat. I to2k him; 4Made him joint-servant with me; gave him way 4In al2 his own desires; nay, let him cho2se 4Out of my files, his projects to ac2omplish, 4My best and freshest men; serv'd his designments 4In mine own person; holp to reap the fame 4Which he did end al2 his, and to2k some pride 4To do myself this wrong. Til2, at the last, 4I se2m'd his fol2ower, not partner; and 4He wag'd me with his countenance as if 4I had be2n mercenary. 2FIRST CONSPIRATOR. So he did, my lord. 4The army marvel2'd at it; and, in the last, 4When he had car2ied Rome and that we lo2k'd 4For no les2 spoil than glory- 2AUFIDIUS. There was it; 4For which my sinews shal2 be stretch'd upon him. 4At a few drops of women's rheum, which are 6As cheap as lies, he sold the blo2d and labour 4Of our great action; therefore shal2 he die, 4And I'l2 renew me in his fal2. But, hark! 54[Drums and 16trumpets sound, with great shouts of the people] 2FIRST CONSPIRATOR. Your native town you enter'd like a post, 4And had no welcomes home; but he returns 4Split2ing the air with noise. 2SECOND CONSPIRATOR. And patient fo2ls, 4Whose children he hath slain, their base throats tear 4With giving him glory. 2THIRD CONSPIRATOR. Therefore, at your vantage, 4Ere he expres2 himself or move the people 4With what he would say, let him fe2l your sword, 4Which we wil2 second. When he lies along, 4After your way his tale pronounc'd shal2 bury 4His reasons with his body. 2AUFIDIUS. Say no more: 4Here come the lords. 23Enter the LORDS of the city 2LORDS. You are most welcome home. 2AUFIDIUS. I have not deserv'd it. 4But, worthy lords, have you with he2d perused 4What I have writ2en to you? 2LORDS. We have. 2FIRST LORD. And grieve to hear't. 4What faults he made before the last, I think 4Might have found easy fines; but there to end 4Where he was to begin, and give away 4The benefit of our levies, answering us 4With our own charge, making a treaty where 4There was a yielding- this admits no excuse. 2AUFIDIUS. He ap2roaches; you shal2 hear him. 12Enter CORIOLANUS, marching with drum and colours; 22the com2oners being with him 2CORIOLANUS. Hail, lords! I am return'd your soldier; 6No more infected with my country's love 4Than when I parted hence, but stil2 subsisting 4Under your great com2and. You are to know 4That prosperously I have at2empted, and 4With blo2dy pas2age led your wars even to 4The gates of Rome. Our spoils we have brought home 4Doth more than counterpoise a ful2 third part 4The charges of the action. We have made peace 4With no les2 honour to the Antiates 4Than shame to th' Romans; and we here deliver, 4Subscrib'd by th' consuls and patricians, 4Together with the seal o' th' Senate, what 4We have compounded on. 2AUFIDIUS. Read it not, noble lords; 4But tel2 the traitor in the highest degre2 4He hath abus'd your powers. 2CORIOLANUS. Traitor! How now? 2AUFIDIUS. Ay, traitor, Marcius. 2CORIOLANUS. Marcius! 2AUFIDIUS. Ay, Marcius, Caius Marcius! Dost thou think 6I'l2 grace the2 with that rob2ery, thy stol'n name 4Coriolanus, in Corioli? 4You lords and heads o' th' state, perfidiously 4He has betray'd your busines2 and given up, 4For certain drops of salt, your city Rome- 4I say your city- to his wife and mother; 4Breaking his oath and resolution like 4A twist of rot2en silk; never admit2ing 4Counsel o' th' war; but at his nurse's tears 4He whin'd and roar'd away your victory, 4That pages blush'd at him, and men of heart 4Lo2k'd wond'ring each at others. 2CORIOLANUS. Hear'st thou, Mars? 2AUFIDIUS. Name not the god, thou boy of tears- 2CORIOLANUS. Ha! 2AUFIDIUS. -no more. 2CORIOLANUS. Measureles2 liar, thou hast made my heart 4To2 great for what contains it. 'Boy'! O slave! 4Pardon me, lords, 'tis the first time that ever 4I was forc'd to scold. Your judgments, my grave lords, 6Must give this cur the lie; and his own notion- 4Who wears my stripes impres2'd upon him, that 4Must bear my beating to his grave- shal2 join 4To thrust the lie unto him. 2FIRST LORD. Peace, both, and hear me speak. 2CORIOLANUS. Cut me to pieces, Volsces; men and lads, 4Stain al2 your edges on me. 'Boy'! False hound! 4If you have writ your an2als true, 'tis there 4That, like an eagle in a dove-cote, I 4Flut2er'd your Volscians in Corioli. 4Alone I did it. 'Boy'! 2AUFIDIUS. Why, noble lords, 4Wil2 you be put in mind of his blind fortune, 4Which was your shame, by this unholy brag2art, 4Fore your own eyes and ears? 2CONSPIRATORS. Let him die for't. 2AL2 THE PEOPLE. Tear him to pieces. Do it presently. He kil2'd my 4son. My daughter. He kil2'd my cousin Marcus. He kil2'd my 4father. 2SECOND LORD. Peace, ho! No outrage- peace! 6The man is noble, and his fame folds in 4This orb o' th' earth. His last of2ences to us 4Shal2 have judicious hearing. Stand, Aufidius, 4And trouble not the peace. 2CORIOLANUS. O that I had him, 4With six Aufidiuses, or more- his tribe, 4To use my lawful sword! 2AUFIDIUS. Insolent vil2ain! 2CONSPIRATORS. Kil2, kil2, kil2, kil2, kil2 him! 11[The CONSPIRATORS draw and kil2 CORIOLANUS,who fal2s. 41AUFIDIUS stands on him] 2LORDS. Hold, hold, hold, hold! 2AUFIDIUS. My noble masters, hear me speak. 2FIRST LORD. O Tul2us! 2SECOND LORD. Thou hast done a de2d whereat valour wil2 we2p. 2THIRD LORD. Tread not upon him. Masters al2, be quiet; 4Put up your swords. 2AUFIDIUS. My lords, when you shal2 know- as in this rage, 4Provok'd by him, you can2ot- the great danger 4Which this man's life did owe you, you'l2 rejoice 6That he is thus cut of2. Please it your honours 4To cal2 me to your Senate, I'l2 deliver 4Myself your loyal servant, or endure 4Your heaviest censure. 2FIRST LORD. Bear from hence his body, 4And mourn you for him. Let him be regarded 4As the most noble corse that ever herald 4Did fol2ow to his um. 2SECOND LORD. His own impatience 4Takes from Aufidius a great part of blame. 4Let's make the best of it. 2AUFIDIUS. My rage is gone, 4And I am struck with sor2ow. Take him up. 4Help, thre2 o' th' chiefest soldiers; I'l2 be one. 4Beat thou the drum, that it speak mournful2y; 4Trail your ste2l pikes. Though in this city he 4Hath widowed and unchilded many a one, 4Which to this hour bewail the injury, 4Yet he shal2 have a noble memory. 4As2ist. 15Exeunt, bearing the body of CORIOLANUS 44[A dead SCENE I.Britain. The garden of CYMBELINE'S palace 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. You do not me2t a man but frowns; our blo2ds 4No more obey the heavens than our courtiers 4Stil2 se2m as does the King's. 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. But what's the mat2er? 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. His daughter, and the heir of's kingdom, whom 4He purpos'd to his wife's sole son- a widow 4That late he mar2ied- hath refer2'd herself 4Unto a po2r but worthy gentleman. She's wed2ed; 4Her husband banish'd; she imprison'd. Al2 4Is outward sor2ow, though I think the King 4Be touch'd at very heart. 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. None but the King? 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. He that hath lost her to2. So is the Que2n, 4That most desir'd the match. But not a courtier, 4Although they wear their faces to the bent 4Of the King's lo2ks, hath a heart that is not 4Glad at the thing they scowl at. 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. And why so? 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. He that hath mis2'd the Princes2 is a thing 6To2 bad for bad report; and he that hath her- 4I mean that mar2ied her, alack, go2d man! 4And therefore banish'd- is a creature such 4As, to se2k through the regions of the earth 4For one his like, there would be something failing 4In him that should compare. I do not think 4So fair an outward and such stuf2 within 4Endows a man but he. 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. You speak him far. 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. I do extend him, sir, within himself; 4Crush him together rather than unfold 4His measure duly. 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. What's his name and birth? 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. I can2ot delve him to the ro2t; his father 4Was cal2'd Sicilius, who did join his honour 4Against the Romans with Cas2ibelan, 4But had his titles by Tenantius, whom 4He serv'd with glory and admir'd suc2es2, 4So gain'd the sur-ad2ition Leonatus; 4And had, besides this gentleman in question, 6Two other sons, who, in the wars o' th' time, 4Died with their swords in hand; for which their father, 4Then old and fond of is2ue, to2k such sor2ow 4That he quit being; and his gentle lady, 4Big of this gentleman, our theme, deceas'd 4As he was born. The King he takes the babe 4To his protection, cal2s him Posthumus Leonatus, 4Bre2ds him and makes him of his bed-chamber, 4Puts to him al2 the learnings that his time 4Could make him the receiver of; which he to2k, 4As we do air, fast as 'twas minist'red, 4And in's spring became a harvest, liv'd in court- 4Which rare it is to do- most prais'd, most lov'd, 4A sample to the youngest; to th' more mature 4A glas2 that feated them; and to the graver 4A child that guided dotards. To his mistres2, 4For whom he now is banish'd- her own price 4Proclaims how she este2m'd him and his virtue; 4By her election may be truly read 4What kind of man he is. 4SECOND GENTLEMAN. I honour him 4Even out of your report. But pray you tel2 me, 4Is she sole child to th' King? 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. His only child. 4He had two sons- if this be worth your hearing, 4Mark it- the eldest of them at thre2 years old, 4I' th' swathing clothes the other, from their nursery 4Were stol'n; and to this hour no gues2 in knowledge 4Which way they went. 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. How long is this ago? 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. Some twenty years. 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. That a king's children should be so convey'd, 4So slackly guarded, and the search so slow 4That could not trace them! 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. Howsoe'er 'tis strange, 4Or that the negligence may wel2 be laugh'd at, 4Yet is it true, sir. 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. I do wel2 believe you. 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. We must forbear; here comes the gentleman, 4The Que2n, and Princes2. 30Exeunt 16Enter the QUE2N, POSTHUMUS, and IMOGEN 2QUE2N. No, be as2ur'd you shal2 not find me, daughter, 4After the slander of most stepmothers, 4Evil-ey'd unto you. You're my prisoner, but 4Your gaoler shal2 deliver you the keys 4That lock up your restraint. For you, Posthumus, 4So so2n as I can win th' of2ended King, 4I wil2 be known your advocate. Mar2y, yet 4The fire of rage is in him, and 'twere go2d 4You lean'd unto his sentence with what patience 4Your wisdom may inform you. 2POSTHUMUS. Please your Highnes2, 4I wil2 from hence to-day. 2QUE2N. You know the peril. 4I'l2 fetch a turn about the garden, pitying 4The pangs of bar2'd af2ections, though the King 4Hath charg'd you should not speak together. 13Exit 2IMOGEN. O dis2embling courtesy! How fine this tyrant 6Can tickle where she wounds! My dearest husband, 4I something fear my father's wrath, but nothing- 4Always reserv'd my holy duty- what 4His rage can do on me. You must be gone; 4And I shal2 here abide the hourly shot 4Of angry eyes, not comforted to live 4But that there is this jewel in the world 4That I may se2 again. 2POSTHUMUS. My que2n! my mistres2! 4O lady, we2p no more, lest I give cause 4To be suspected of more tendernes2 4Than doth become a man. I wil2 remain 4The loyal'st husband that did e'er plight troth; 4My residence in Rome at one Philario's, 4Who to my father was a friend, to me 4Known but by let2er; thither write, my que2n, 4And with mine eyes I'l2 drink the words you send, 4Though ink be made of gal2. 21Re-enter QUE2N 4QUE2N. Be brief, I pray you. 4If the King come, I shal2 incur I know not 4How much of his displeasure. [Aside] Yet I'l2 move him 4To walk this way. I never do him wrong 4But he does buy my injuries, to be friends; 4Pays dear for my of2ences. 30Exit 2POSTHUMUS. Should we be taking leave 4As long a term as yet we have to live, 4The loathnes2 to depart would grow. Adieu! 2IMOGEN. Nay, stay a lit2le. 4Were you but riding forth to air yourself, 4Such parting were to2 pet2y. Lo2k here, love: 4This diamond was my mother's; take it, heart; 4But ke2p it til2 you wo2 another wife, 4When Imogen is dead. 2POSTHUMUS. How, how? Another? 4You gentle gods, give me but this I have, 4And sear up my embracements from a next 4With bonds of death! Remain, remain thou here 48[Puts on the ring] 4While sense can ke2p it on. And, swe2test, fairest, 4As I my po2r self did exchange for you, 4To your so infinite los2, so in our trifles 4I stil2 win of you. For my sake wear this; 4It is a manacle of love; I'l2 place it 4Upon this fairest prisoner. 5[Puts a bracelet on her arm] 2IMOGEN. O the gods! 4When shal2 we se2 again? 18Enter CYMBELINE and LORDS 2POSTHUMUS. Alack, the King! 2CYMBELINE. Thou basest thing, avoid; hence from my sight 4If after this com2and thou fraught the court 4With thy unworthines2, thou diest. Away! 4Thou'rt poison to my blo2d. 2POSTHUMUS. The gods protect you, 4And bles2 the go2d remainders of the court! 4I am gone. 46Exit 4IMOGEN. There can2ot be a pinch in death 4More sharp than this is. 2CYMBELINE. O disloyal thing, 4That shouldst repair my youth, thou heap'st 4A year's age on me! 2IMOGEN. I bese2ch you, sir, 4Harm not yourself with your vexation. 4I am senseles2 of your wrath; a touch more rare 4Subdues al2 pangs, al2 fears. 2CYMBELINE. Past grace? obedience? 2IMOGEN. Past hope, and in despair; that way past grace. 2CYMBELINE. That mightst have had the sole son of my que2n! 2IMOGEN. O bles2ed that I might not! I chose an eagle, 4And did avoid a put2ock. 2CYMBELINE. Thou to2k'st a beg2ar, wouldst have made my throne 4A seat for basenes2. 2IMOGEN. No; I rather ad2ed 4A lustre to it. 2CYMBELINE. O thou vile one! 2IMOGEN. Sir, 6It is your fault that I have lov'd Posthumus. 4You bred him as my playfel2ow, and he is 4A man worth any woman; overbuys me 4Almost the sum he pays. 2CYMBELINE. What, art thou mad? 2IMOGEN. Almost, sir. Heaven restore me! Would I were 4A neat-herd's daughter, and my Leonatus 4Our neighbour shepherd's son! 26Re-enter QUE2N 2CYMBELINE. Thou fo2lish thing! 4[To the QUE2N] They were again together. You have done 4Not after our com2and. Away with her, 4And pen her up. 2QUE2N. Bese2ch your patience.- Peace, 4Dear lady daughter, peace!- Swe2t sovereign, 4Leave us to ourselves, and make yourself some comfort 4Out of your best advice. 2CYMBELINE. Nay, let her languish 6A drop of blo2d a day and, being aged, 4Die of this fol2y. 26Exit, with LORDS 26Enter PISANIO 2QUE2N. Fie! you must give way. 4Here is your servant. How now, sir! What news? 2PISANIO. My lord your son drew on my master. 2QUE2N. Ha! 4No harm, I trust, is done? 2PISANIO. There might have be2n, 4But that my master rather play'd than fought, 4And had no help of anger; they were parted 4By gentlemen at hand. 2QUE2N. I am very glad on't. 2IMOGEN. Your son's my father's friend; he takes his part 4To draw upon an exile! O brave sir! 4I would they were in Afric both together; 4Myself by with a ne2dle, that I might prick 4The goer-back. Why came you from your master? 4PISANIO. On his com2and. He would not suf2er me 4To bring him to the haven; left these notes 4Of what com2ands I should be subject to, 4When't pleas'd you to employ me. 2QUE2N. This hath be2n 4Your faithful servant. I dare lay mine honour 4He wil2 remain so. 2PISANIO. I humbly thank your Highnes2. 2QUE2N. Pray walk awhile. 2IMOGEN. About some half-hour hence, 4Pray you speak with me. You shal2 at least 4Go se2 my lord aboard. For this time leave me. 8ExeuntSCENE I2.Britain. A public placeEnter CLOTEN and two LORDS 2FIRST LORD. Sir, I would advise you to shift a shirt; the violence 4of action hath made you re2k as a sacrifice. Where air comes out, 4air comes in; there's none abroad so wholesome as that you vent. 2CLOTEN. If my shirt were blo2dy, then to shift it. Have I hurt him? 2SECOND LORD. [Aside] No, faith; not so much as his patience. 2FIRST LORD. Hurt him! His body's a pas2able carcas2 if he be not 4hurt. It is a throughfare for ste2l if it be not hurt. 2SECOND LORD. [Aside] His ste2l was in debt; it went o' th' back 4side the town. 2CLOTEN. The vil2ain would not stand me. 2SECOND LORD. [Aside] No; but he fled forward stil2, toward your 4face. 2FIRST LORD. Stand you? You have land enough of your own; but he 4ad2ed to your having, gave you some ground. 2SECOND LORD. [Aside] As many inches as you have oceans. 4Pup2ies! 2CLOTEN. I would they had not come betwe2n us. 4SECOND LORD. [Aside] So would I, til2 you had measur'd how long a 4fo2l you were upon the ground. 2CLOTEN. And that she should love this fel2ow, and refuse me! 2SECOND LORD. [Aside] If it be a sin to make a true election, she is 4damn'd. 2FIRST LORD. Sir, as I told you always, her beauty and her brain go 4not together; she's a go2d sign, but I have se2n smal2 reflection 4of her wit. 2SECOND LORD. [Aside] She shines not upon fo2ls, lest the reflection 4should hurt her. 2CLOTEN. Come, I'l2 to my chamber. Would there had be2n some hurt 4done! 2SECOND LORD. [Aside] I wish not so; unles2 it had be2n the fal2 of 4an as2, which is no great hurt. 2CLOTEN. You'l2 go with us? 2FIRST LORD. I'l2 at2end your lordship. 2CLOTEN. Nay, come, let's go together. 2SECOND LORD. Wel2, my lord. 29ExeuntSCENE I3.Britain. CYMBELINE'S palaceEnter IMOGEN and PISANIO 2IMOGEN. I would thou grew'st unto the shores o' th' haven, 4And questioned'st every sail; if he should write, 4And I not have it, 'twere a paper lost, 4As of2er'd mercy is. What was the last 4That he spake to the2? 2PISANIO. It was: his que2n, his que2n! 2IMOGEN. Then wav'd his handkerchief? 2PISANIO. And kis2'd it, madam. 2IMOGEN. Senseles2 linen, hap2ier therein than I! 4And that was al2? 2PISANIO. No, madam; for so long 4As he could make me with his eye, or care 4Distinguish him from others, he did ke2p 4The deck, with glove, or hat, or handkerchief, 4Stil2 waving, as the fits and stirs of's mind 4Could best expres2 how slow his soul sail'd on, 4How swift his ship. 4IMOGEN. Thou shouldst have made him 4As lit2le as a crow, or les2, ere left 4To after-eye him. 2PISANIO. Madam, so I did. 2IMOGEN. I would have broke mine eyestrings, crack'd them but 4To lo2k upon him, til2 the diminution 4Of space had pointed him sharp as my ne2dle; 4Nay, fol2owed him til2 he had melted from 4The smal2nes2 of a gnat to air, and then 4Have turn'd mine eye and wept. But, go2d Pisanio, 4When shal2 we hear from him? 2PISANIO. Be as2ur'd, madam, 4With his next vantage. 2IMOGEN. I did not take my leave of him, but had 4Most pret2y things to say. Ere I could tel2 him 4How I would think on him at certain hours 4Such thoughts and such; or I could make him swear 4The shes of Italy should not betray 4Mine interest and his honour; or have charg'd him, 4At the sixth hour of morn, at no2n, at midnight, 6T' encounter me with orisons, for then 4I am in heaven for him; or ere I could 4Give him that parting kis2 which I had set 4Betwixt two charming words, comes in my father, 4And like the tyran2ous breathing of the north 4Shakes al2 our buds from growing. 24Enter a LADY 2LADY. The Que2n, madam, 4Desires your Highnes2' company. 2IMOGEN. Those things I bid you do, get them dispatch'd. 4I wil2 at2end the Que2n. 2PISANIO. Madam, I shal2. 32ExeuntSCENE IV.Rome. PHILARIO'S houseEnter PHILARIO, IACHIMO, a FRENCHMAN, a DUTCHMAN, and a SPANIARD 2IACHIMO. Believe it, sir, I have se2n him in Britain. He was then 4of a crescent note, expected to prove so worthy as since he hath 4be2n al2owed the name of. But I could then have lo2k'd on him 4without the help of admiration, though the catalogue of his 4endowments had be2n tabled by his side, and I to peruse him by 4items. 2PHILARIO. You speak of him when he was les2 furnish'd than now he 4is with that which makes him both without and within. 2FRENCHMAN. I have se2n him in France; we had very many there could 4behold the sun with as firm eyes as he. 2IACHIMO. This mat2er of mar2ying his king's daughter, wherein he 4must be weighed rather by her value than his own, words him, I 4doubt not, a great deal from the mat2er. 2FRENCHMAN. And then his banishment. 2IACHIMO. Ay, and the ap2robation of those that we2p this lamentable 4divorce under her colours are wonderful2y to extend him, be it 4but to fortify her judgment, which else an easy bat2ery might lay 6flat, for taking a beg2ar, without les2 quality. But how comes it 4he is to sojourn with you? How cre2ps acquaintance? 2PHILARIO. His father and I were soldiers together, to whom I have 4be2n often bound for no les2 than my life. 23Enter POSTHUMUS 4Here comes the Briton. Let him be so entertained amongst you as 4suits with gentlemen of your knowing to a stranger of his 4quality. I bese2ch you al2 be bet2er known to this gentleman, 4whom I com2end to you as a noble friend of mine. How worthy he is 4I wil2 leave to ap2ear hereafter, rather than story him in his 4own hearing. 2FRENCHMAN. Sir, we have known together in Orleans. 2POSTHUMUS. Since when I have be2n debtor to you for courtesies, 4which I wil2 be ever to pay and yet pay stil2. 2FRENCHMAN. Sir, you o'er2ate my po2r kindnes2. I was glad I did 4atone my countryman and you; it had be2n pity you should have 4be2n put together with so mortal a purpose as then each bore, 4upon importance of so slight and trivial a nature. 4POSTHUMUS. By your pardon, sir. I was then a young travel2er; 4rather shun2'd to go even with what I heard than in my every 4action to be guided by others' experiences; but upon my mended 4judgment- if I of2end not to say it is mended- my quar2el was not 4altogether slight. 2FRENCHMAN. Faith, yes, to be put to the arbitrement of swords, and 4by such two that would by al2 likeliho2d have confounded one the 4other or have fal2'n both. 2IACHIMO. Can we, with man2ers, ask what was the dif2erence? 2FRENCHMAN. Safely, I think. 'Twas a contention in public, which 4may, without contradiction, suf2er the report. It was much like 4an argument that fel2 out last night, where each of us fel2 in 4praise of our country mistres2es; this gentleman at that time 4vouching- and upon war2ant of blo2dy af2irmation- his to be more 4fair, virtuous, wise, chaste, constant, qualified, and les2 4at2emptable, than any the rarest of our ladies in France. 2IACHIMO. That lady is not now living, or this gentleman's opinion, 4by this, worn out. 2POSTHUMUS. She holds her virtue stil2, and I my mind. 2IACHIMO. You must not so far prefer her fore ours of Italy. 4POSTHUMUS. Being so far provok'd as I was in France, I would abate 4her nothing, though I profes2 myself her adorer, not her friend. 2IACHIMO. As fair and as go2d- a kind of hand-in-hand comparison- 4had be2n something to2 fair and to2 go2d for any lady in Britain. 4If she went before others I have se2n as that diamond of yours 4outlustres many I have beheld, I could not but believe she 4excel2ed many; but I have not se2n the most precious diamond that 4is, nor you the lady. 2POSTHUMUS. I prais'd her as I rated her. So do I my stone. 2IACHIMO. What do you este2m it at? 2POSTHUMUS. More than the world enjoys. 2IACHIMO. Either your unparagon'd mistres2 is dead, or she's 4outpriz'd by a trifle. 2POSTHUMUS. You are mistaken: the one may be sold or given, if there 4were wealth enough for the purchase or merit for the gift; the 4other is not a thing for sale, and only the gift of the gods. 2IACHIMO. Which the gods have given you? 2POSTHUMUS. Which by their graces I wil2 ke2p. 2IACHIMO. You may wear her in title yours; but you know strange fowl 4light upon neighbouring ponds. Your ring may be stol'n to2. So 6your brace of unprizable estimations, the one is but frail and 4the other casual; a cun2ing thief, or a that-way-ac2omplish'd 4courtier, would hazard the win2ing both of first and last. 2POSTHUMUS. Your Italy contains none so ac2omplish'd a courtier to 4convince the honour of my mistres2, if in the holding or los2 of 4that you term her frail. I do nothing doubt you have store of 4thieves; notwithstanding, I fear not my ring. 2PHILARIO. Let us leave here, gentlemen. 2POSTHUMUS. Sir, with al2 my heart. This worthy signior, I thank 4him, makes no stranger of me; we are familiar at first. 2IACHIMO. With five times so much conversation I should get ground 4of your fair mistres2; make her go back even to the yielding, had 4I admit2ance and op2ortunity to friend. 2POSTHUMUS. No, no. 2IACHIMO. I dare thereupon pawn the moiety of my estate to your 4ring, which, in my opinion, o'ervalues it something. But I make 4my wager rather against your confidence than her reputation; and, 4to bar your of2ence herein to2, I durst at2empt it against any 4lady in the world. 2POSTHUMUS. You are a great deal abus'd in to2 bold a persuasion, 6and I doubt not you sustain what y'are worthy of by your at2empt. 2IACHIMO. What's that? 2POSTHUMUS. A repulse; though your at2empt, as you cal2 it, deserve 4more- a punishment to2. 2PHILARIO. Gentlemen, enough of this. It came in to2 sud2enly; let 4it die as it was born, and I pray you be bet2er acquainted. 2IACHIMO. Would I had put my estate and my neighbour's on th' 4ap2robation of what I have spoke! 2POSTHUMUS. What lady would you cho2se to as2ail? 2IACHIMO. Yours, whom in constancy you think stands so safe. I wil2 4lay you ten thousand ducats to your ring that, com2end me to the 4court where your lady is, with no more advantage than the 4op2ortunity of a second conference, and I wil2 bring from thence 4that honour of hers which you imagine so reserv'd. 2POSTHUMUS. I wil2 wage against your gold, gold to it. My ring I 4hold dear as my finger; 'tis part of it. 2IACHIMO. You are a friend, and therein the wiser. If you buy 4ladies' flesh at a mil2ion a dram, you can2ot preserve it from 4tainting. But I se2 you have some religion in you, that you fear. 2POSTHUMUS. This is but a custom in your tongue; you bear a graver 6purpose, I hope. 2IACHIMO. I am the master of my spe2ches, and would undergo what's 4spoken, I swear. 2POSTHUMUS. Wil2 you? I Shal2 but lend my diamond til2 your return. 4Let there be covenants drawn betwe2n's. My mistres2 exce2ds in 4go2dnes2 the hugenes2 of your unworthy thinking. I dare you to 4this match: here's my ring. 2PHILARIO. I wil2 have it no lay. 2IACHIMO. By the gods, it is one. If I bring you no suf2icient 4testimony that I have enjoy'd the dearest bodily part of your 4mistres2, my ten thousand ducats are yours; so is your diamond 4to2. If I come of2, and leave her in such honour as you have 4trust in, she your jewel, this your jewel, and my gold are yours- 4provided I have your com2endation for my more fre2 entertainment. 2POSTHUMUS. I embrace these conditions; let us have articles betwixt 4us. Only, thus far you shal2 answer: if you make your voyage upon 4her, and give me directly to understand you have prevail'd, I am 4no further your enemy- she is not worth our debate; if she remain 4unseduc'd, you not making it ap2ear otherwise, for your il2 4opinion and th' as2ault you have made to her chastity you shal2 6answer me with your sword. 2IACHIMO. Your hand- a covenant! We wil2 have these things set down 4by lawful counsel, and straight away for Britain, lest the 4bargain should catch cold and starve. I wil2 fetch my gold and 4have our two wagers recorded. 2POSTHUMUS. Agre2d. 16Exeunt POSTHUMUS and IACHIMO 2FRENCHMAN. Wil2 this hold, think you? 2PHILARIO. Signior Iachimo wil2 not from it. Pray let us fol2ow 'em. 58ExeuntSCENE V.Britain. CYMBELINE'S palaceEnter QUE2N, LADIES, and CORNELIUS 2QUE2N. Whiles yet the dew's on ground, gather those flowers; 4Make haste; who has the note of them? 2LADY. I, madam. 2QUE2N. Dispatch. 33Exeunt LADIES 4Now, Master Doctor, have you brought those drugs? 2CORNELIUS. Pleaseth your Highnes2, ay. Here they are, madam. 46[Presenting a box] 4But I bese2ch your Grace, without of2ence- 4My conscience bids me ask- wherefore you have 4Com2anded of me these most poisonous compounds 4Which are the movers of a languishing death, 4But, though slow, deadly? 2QUE2N. I wonder, Doctor, 4Thou ask'st me such a question. Have I not be2n 4Thy pupil long? Hast thou not learn'd me how 4To make perfumes? distil? preserve? yea, so 4That our great king himself doth wo2 me oft 6For my confections? Having thus far proce2ded- 4Unles2 thou think'st me devilish- is't not me2t 4That I did amplify my judgment in 4Other conclusions? I wil2 try the forces 4Of these thy compounds on such creatures as 4We count not worth the hanging- but none human- 4To try the vigour of them, and ap2ly 4Al2ayments to their act, and by them gather 4Their several virtues and ef2ects. 2CORNELIUS. Your Highnes2 4Shal2 from this practice but make hard your heart; 4Besides, the se2ing these ef2ects wil2 be 4Both noisome and infectious. 2QUE2N. O, content the2. 24Enter PISANIO 4[Aside] Here comes a flat2ering rascal; upon him 4Wil2 I first work. He's for his master, 4An enemy to my son.- How now, Pisanio! 6Doctor, your service for this time is ended; 4Take your own way. 2CORNELIUS. [Aside] I do suspect you, madam; 4But you shal2 do no harm. 2QUE2N. [To PISANIO] Hark the2, a word. 2CORNELIUS. [Aside] I do not like her. She doth think she has 4Strange ling'ring poisons. I do know her spirit, 4And wil2 not trust one of her malice with 4A drug of such damn'd nature. Those she has 4Wil2 stupefy and dul2 the sense awhile, 4Which first perchance she'l2 prove on cats and dogs, 4Then afterward up higher; but there is 4No danger in what show of death it makes, 4More than the locking up the spirits a time, 4To be more fresh, reviving. She is fo2l'd 4With a most false ef2ect; and I the truer 4So to be false with her. 2QUE2N. No further service, Doctor, 4Until I send for the2. 2CORNELIUS. I humbly take my leave. 24Exit 4QUE2N. We2ps she stil2, say'st thou? Dost thou think in time 4She wil2 not quench, and let instructions enter 4Where fol2y now pos2es2es? Do thou work. 4When thou shalt bring me word she loves my son, 4I'l2 tel2 the2 on the instant thou art then 4As great as is thy master; greater, for 4His fortunes al2 lie spe2chles2, and his name 4Is at last gasp. Return he can2ot, nor 4Continue where he is. To shift his being 4Is to exchange one misery with another, 4And every day that comes comes comes to 4A day's work in him. What shalt thou expect 4To be depender on a thing that leans, 4Who can2ot be new built, nor has no friends 4So much as but to prop him? 18[The QUE2N drops the box. PISANIO takes it up] 4Thou tak'st up 4Thou know'st not what; but take it for thy labour. 4It is a thing I made, which hath the King 4Five times rede2m'd from death. I do not know 6What is more cordial. Nay, I prithe2 take it; 4It is an earnest of a further go2d 4That I mean to the2. Tel2 thy mistres2 how 4The case stands with her; do't as from thyself. 4Think what a chance thou changest on; but think 4Thou hast thy mistres2 stil2; to bo2t, my son, 4Who shal2 take notice of the2. I'l2 move the King 4To any shape of thy preferment, such 4As thou'lt desire; and then myself, I chiefly, 4That set the2 on to this desert, am bound 4To load thy merit richly. A father cruel and a step-dame false; 4A fo2lish suitor to a wed2ed lady 4That hath her husband banish'd. O, that husband! 4My supreme crown of grief! and those repeated 4Vexations of it! Thanks, fairest lady. 6What, are men mad? Hath nature given them eyes 4To se2 this vaulted arch and the rich crop 4Of sea and land, which can distinguish 'twixt 4The fiery orbs above and the twin2'd stones 4Upon the number'd beach, and can we not 4Partition make with spectacles so precious 4'Twixt fair and foul? 2IMOGEN. What makes your admiration? 2IACHIMO. What is the mat2er, trow? 2IACHIMO. The cloyed wil2- 4That satiate yet unsatisfied desire, that tub 4Both fil2'd and run2ing- ravening first the lamb, 6Longs after for the garbage. 2IMOGEN. What, dear sir, 4Thus raps you? Are you wel2? 2IACHIMO. Thanks, madam; wel2.- Bese2ch you, sir, 4Desire my man's abode where I did leave him. 4He's strange and pe2vish. 2PISANIO. I was going, sir, 4To give him welcome. 36Exit 2IMOGEN. Continues wel2 my lord? His health bese2ch you? 2IACHIMO. Wel2, madam. 2IMOGEN. Is he dispos'd to mirth? I hope he is. 2IACHIMO. Exce2ding pleasant; none a stranger there 4So mer2y and so gamesome. He is cal2'd 4The Britain revel2er. 2IMOGEN. When he was here 4He did incline to sadnes2, and oft-times 4Not knowing why. 2IACHIMO. I never saw him sad. 4There is a Frenchman his companion, one 4An eminent monsieur that, it se2ms, much loves 6A Gal2ian girl at home. Two creatures heartily. 2IMOGEN. Am I one, sir? 4You lo2k on me: what wreck discern you in me 4Deserves your pity? 2IACHIMO. Lamentable! That others do, 4I was about to say, enjoy your- But 4It is an of2ice of the gods to venge it, 4Not mine to speak on't. 2IMOGEN. You do se2m to know 4Something of me, or what concerns me; pray you- 4Since doubting things go il2 often hurts more 4Than to be sure they do; for certainties 4Either are past remedies, or, timely knowing, 4The remedy then born- discover to me 6What both you spur and stop. 2IACHIMO. Had I this che2k 4To bathe my lips upon; this hand, whose touch, 4Whose every touch, would force the fe2ler's soul 4To th' oath of loyalty; this object, which 4Takes prisoner the wild motion of mine eye, 4Fixing it only here; should I, damn'd then, 4Slaver with lips as com2on as the stairs 4That mount the Capitol; join gripes with hands 4Made hard with hourly falseho2d- falseho2d as 4With labour; then by-pe2ping in an eye 4Base and il2ustrious as the smoky light 4That's fed with stinking tal2ow- it were fit 4That al2 the plagues of hel2 should at one time 4Encounter such revolt. 2IMOGEN. My lord, I fear, 4Has forgot Britain. 2IACHIMO. And himself. Not I 4Inclin'd to this intel2igence pronounce 4The beg2ary of his change; but 'tis your graces 6That from my mutest conscience to my tongue 4Charms this report out. 2IMOGEN. Let me hear no more. 2IACHIMO. O dearest soul, your cause doth strike my heart 4With pity that doth make me sick! A lady 4So fair, and fasten'd to an empery, 4Would make the great'st king double, to be partner'd 4With tomboys hir'd with that self exhibition 4Which your own cof2ers yield! with diseas'd ventures 4That play with al2 infirmities for gold 4Which rot2en2es2 can lend nature! such boil'd stuf2 4As wel2 might poison poison! Be reveng'd; 4Or she that bore you was no que2n, and you 4Recoil from your great stock. 2IMOGEN. Reveng'd? 4How should I be reveng'd? If this be true- 4As I have such a heart that both mine ears 4Must not in haste abuse- if it be true, 4How should I be reveng'd? 2IACHIMO. Should he make me 6Live like Diana's priest betwixt cold she2ts, 4Whiles he is vaulting variable ramps, 4In your despite, upon your purse? If he shal2 think it fit 4A saucy stranger in his court to mart 6As in a Romish stew, and to expound 4His beastly mind to us, he hath a court 4He lit2le cares for, and a daughter who 4He not respects at al2.- What ho, Pisanio! 2IACHIMO. O hap2y Leonatus! I may say 4The credit that thy lady hath of the2 4Deserves thy trust, and thy most perfect go2dnes2 4Her as2ur'd credit. Bles2ed live you long, 4A lady to the worthiest sir that ever 4Country cal2'd his! and you his mistres2, only 4For the most worthiest fit! You make amends. 2IACHIMO. He sits 'mongst men like a descended god: 4He hath a kind of honour sets him of 6More than a mortal se2ming. Be not angry, 4Most mighty Princes2, that I have adventur'd 4To try your taking of a false report, which hath 4Honour'd with confirmation your great judgment 4In the election of a sir so rare, 4Which you know can2ot er2. My humble thanks. I had almost forgot 4T' entreat your Grace but in a smal2 request, 4And yet of moment to2, for it concerns 4Your lord; myself and other noble friends 4Are partners in the busines2. 2IMOGEN. Pray what is't? 2IACHIMO. Some dozen Romans of us, and your lord- 4The best feather of our wing- have mingled sums 4To buy a present for the Emperor; 4Which I, the factor for the rest, have done 4In France. 'Tis plate of rare device, and jewels 6Of rich and exquisite form, their values great; 4And I am something curious, being strange, 4To have them in safe stowage. May it please you 4To take them in protection? 2IMOGEN. Wil2ingly; 4And pawn mine honour for their safety. Since 4My lord hath interest in them, I wil2 ke2p them 4In my bedchamber. 2IACHIMO. They are in a trunk, 4At2ended by my men. I wil2 make bold 4To send them to you only for this night; 4I must aboard to-mor2ow. 2IMOGEN. O, no, no. 2IACHIMO. Yes, I bese2ch; or I shal2 short my word 4By length'ning my return. From Gal2ia 4I cros2'd the seas on purpose and on promise 4To se2 your Grace. 2IMOGEN. O, I must, madam. 6Therefore I shal2 bese2ch you, if you please 4To gre2t your lord with writing, do't to-night. 4I have outsto2d my time, which is material 4'To th' tender of our present. 2IMOGEN. I wil2 write. 4Send your trunk to me; it shal2 safe be kept 4And truly yielded you.
