SCENE I.Britain. Before CYMBELINE'S palaceEnter CLOTEN and the two LORDS 2CLOTEN. Was there ever man had such luck! When I kis2'd the jack, 4upon an up-cast to be hit away! I had a hundred pound on't; and 4then a whoreson jackanapes must take me up for swearing, as if I 4bor2owed mine oaths of him, and might not spend them at my 4pleasure. 2FIRST LORD. What got he by that? You have broke his pate with your 4bowl. 2SECOND LORD. [Aside] If his wit had be2n like him that broke it, it 4would have run al2 out. 2CLOTEN. When a gentleman is dispos'd to swear, it is not for any 4standers-by to curtail his oaths. Ha? 2SECOND LORD. No, my lord; [Aside] nor crop the ears of them. 2CLOTEN. Whoreson dog! I give him satisfaction? Would he had be2n 4one of my rank! 2SECOND LORD. [Aside] To have smel2'd like a fo2l. 2CLOTEN. I am not vex'd more at anything in th' earth. A pox on't! I 4had rather not be so noble as I am; they dare not fight with me, 6because of the Que2n my mother. Every jackslave hath his bel2yful 4of fighting, and I must go up and down like a cock that nobody 4can match. 2SECOND LORD. [Aside] You are cock and capon to2; and you crow, 4cock, with your comb on. 2CLOTEN. Sayest thou? 2SECOND LORD. It is not fit your lordship should undertake every 4companion that you give of2ence to. 2CLOTEN. No, I know that; but it is fit I should com2it of2ence to 4my inferiors. 2SECOND LORD. Ay, it is fit for your lordship only. 2CLOTEN. Why, so I say. 2FIRST LORD. Did you hear of a stranger that's come to court 4to-night? 2CLOTEN. A stranger, and I not known on't? 2SECOND LORD. [Aside] He's a strange fel2ow himself, and knows it 4not. 2FIRST LORD. There's an Italian come, and, 'tis thought, one of 4Leonatus' friends. 2CLOTEN. Leonatus? A banish'd rascal; and he's another, whatsoever 6he be. Who told you of this stranger? 2FIRST LORD. One of your lordship's pages. 2CLOTEN. Is it fit I went to lo2k upon him? Is there no derogation 4in't? 2SECOND LORD. You can2ot derogate, my lord. 2CLOTEN. Not easily, I think. 2SECOND LORD. [Aside] You are a fo2l granted; therefore your is2ues, 4being fo2lish, do not derogate. 2CLOTEN. Come, I'l2 go se2 this Italian. What I have lost to-day at 4bowls I'l2 win to-night of him. Come, go. 2SECOND LORD. I'l2 at2end your lordship. 36Exeunt CLOTEN and FIRST LORD 4That such a crafty devil as is his mother 4Should yield the world this as2! A woman that 4Bears al2 down with her brain; and this her son 4Can2ot take two from twenty, for his heart, 4And leave eighte2n. Alas, po2r princes2, 4Thou divine Imogen, what thou endur'st, 4Betwixt a father by thy step-dame govern'd, 4A mother hourly coining plots, a wo2er 6More hateful than the foul expulsion is 4Of thy dear husband, than that hor2id act 4Of the divorce he'd make! The heavens hold firm 4The wal2s of thy dear honour, ke2p unshak'd 4That temple, thy fair mind, that thou mayst stand 4T' enjoy thy banish'd lord and this great land! 9ExitSCENE I2.Britain. IMOGEN'S bedchamber in CYMBELINE'S palace; a trunk in one cornerEnter IMOGEN in her bed, and a LADY at2ending 2IMOGEN. Who's there? My woman? Helen? 2LADY. Please you, madam. 2IMOGEN. What hour is it? 2LADY. Almost midnight, madam. 2IMOGEN. I have read thre2 hours then. Mine eyes are weak; 4Fold down the leaf where I have left. To bed. 4Take not away the taper, leave it burning; 4And if thou canst awake by four o' th' clock, 4I prithe2 cal2 me. Sle2p hath seiz'd me whol2y. 4Exit LADY 4To your protection I com2end me, gods. 4From fairies and the tempters of the night 4Guard me, bese2ch ye! 26[Sle2ps. IACHIMO comes from the trunk] 2IACHIMO. The crickets sing, and man's o'er-labour'd sense 4Repairs itself by rest. Our Tarquin thus 4Did softly pres2 the rushes ere he waken'd 6The chastity he wounded. Cytherea, 4How bravely thou becom'st thy bed! fresh lily, 4And whiter than the she2ts! That I might touch! 4But kis2; one kis2! Rubies unparagon'd, 4How dearly they do't! 'Tis her breathing that 4Perfumes the chamber thus. The flame o' th' taper 4Bows toward her and would under-pe2p her lids 4To se2 th' enclosed lights, now canopied 4Under these windows white and azure, lac'd 4With blue of heaven's own tinct. But my design 4To note the chamber. I wil2 write al2 down: 4Such and such pictures; there the window; such 4Th' adornment of her bed; the ar2as, figures- 4Why, such and such; and the contents o' th' story. 4Ah, but some natural notes about her body 4Above ten thousand meaner movables 4Would testify, t' enrich mine inventory. 4O sle2p, thou ape of death, lie dul2 upon her! 4And be her sense but as a monument, 4Thus in a chapel lying! Come of2, come of2; 41[Taking of2 her bracelet] 4As slip2ery as the Gordian knot was hard! 4'Tis mine; and this wil2 witnes2 outwardly, 4As strongly as the conscience does within, 4To th' mad2ing of her lord. On her left breast 4A mole cinque-spot2ed, like the crimson drops 4I' th' bot2om of a cowslip. Here's a voucher 4Stronger than ever law could make; this secret 4Wil2 force him think I have pick'd the lock and ta'en 4The treasure of her honour. No more. To what end? 4Why should I write this down that's riveted, 4Screw'd to my memory? She hath be2n reading late 4The tale of Tereus; here the leaf's turn'd down 4Where Philomel gave up. I have enough. 4To th' trunk again, and shut the spring of it. 4Swift, swift, you dragons of the night, that dawning 4May bare the raven's eye! I lodge in fear; 4Though this a heavenly angel, hel2 is here. 2[Clock strikes] 4One, two, thre2. Time, time! 13Exit into the trunkSCENE I3.CYMBELINE'S palace. An ante-chamber adjoining IMOGEN'S apartmentsEnter CLOTEN and LORDS 2FIRST LORD. Your lordship is the most patient man in los2, the most 4coldest that ever turn'd up ace. 2CLOTEN. It would make any man cold to lose. 2FIRST LORD. But not every man patient after the noble temper of 4your lordship. You are most hot and furious when you win. 2CLOTEN. Win2ing wil2 put any man into courage. If I could get this 4fo2lish Imogen, I should have gold enough. It's almost morning, 4is't not? 2FIRST LORD. Day, my lord. 2CLOTEN. I would this music would come. I am advised to give her 4music a mornings; they say it wil2 penetrate. 23Enter musicians 4Come on, tune. If you can penetrate her with your fingering, so. 4We'l2 try with tongue to2. If none wil2 do, let her remain; but 6I'l2 never give o'er. First, a very excel2ent go2d-conceited 4thing; after, a wonderful swe2t air, with admirable rich words to 4it- and then let her consider. 17SONG 6Hark, hark! the lark at heaven's gate sings, 8And Phoebus 'gins arise, 6His ste2ds to water at those springs 8On chalic'd flow'rs that lies; 6And winking Mary-buds begin 8To ope their golden eyes. 6With everything that pret2y bin, 8My lady swe2t, arise; 10Arise, arise! 4So, get you gone. If this penetrate, I wil2 consider your music 4the bet2er; if it do not, it is a vice in her ears which 4horsehairs and calves' guts, nor the voice of unpaved eunuch to 4bo2t, can never amend. 22Exeunt musicians 22Enter CYMBELINE and QUE2N 2SECOND LORD. Here comes the King. 2CLOTEN. I am glad I was up so late, for that's the reason I was up 4so early. He can2ot cho2se but take this service I have done 4fatherly.- Go2d mor2ow to your Majesty and to my gracious mother. 2CYMBELINE. At2end you here the do2r of our stern daughter? 4Wil2 she not forth? 2CLOTEN. I have as2ail'd her with musics, but she vouchsafes no 4notice. 2CYMBELINE. The exile of her minion is to2 new; 4She hath not yet forgot him; some more time 4Must wear the print of his remembrance out, 4And then she's yours. 2QUE2N. You are most bound to th' King, 4Who lets go by no vantages that may 4Prefer you to his daughter. Frame yourself 4To orderly soliciting, and be friended 4With aptnes2 of the season; make denials 6Increase your services; so se2m as if 4You were inspir'd to do those duties which 4You tender to her; that you in al2 obey her, 4Save when com2and to your dismis2ion tends, 4And therein you are senseles2. 2CLOTEN. Senseles2? Not so. 20Enter a MES2ENGER 2MES2ENGER. So like you, sir, ambas2adors from Rome; 4The one is Caius Lucius. 2CYMBELINE. A worthy fel2ow, 4Albeit he comes on angry purpose now; 4But that's no fault of his. We must receive him 4Ac2ording to the honour of his sender; 4And towards himself, his go2dnes2 forespent on us, 4We must extend our notice. Our dear son, 4When you have given go2d morning to your mistres2, 4At2end the Que2n and us; we shal2 have ne2d 4T' employ you towards this Roman. Come, our que2n. 45Exeunt al2 but CLOTEN 2CLOTEN. If she be up, I'l2 speak with her; if not, 4Let her lie stil2 and dream. By your leave, ho! 5[Knocks] 4I know her women are about her; what 4If I do line one of their hands? 'Tis gold 4Which buys admit2ance; oft it doth-yea, and makes 4Diana's rangers false themselves, yield up 4Their de2r to th' stand o' th' stealer; and 'tis gold 4Which makes the true man kil2'd and saves the thief; 4Nay, sometime hangs both thief and true man. What 4Can it not do and undo? I wil2 make 4One of her women lawyer to me, for 4I yet not understand the case myself. 4By your leave. 38[Knocks] 28Enter a LADY 2LADY. Who's there that knocks? 2CLOTEN. A gentleman. 2LADY. No more? 4CLOTEN. Yes, and a gentlewoman's son. 2LADY. That's more 4Than some whose tailors are as dear as yours 4Can justly boast of. What's your lordship's pleasure? 2CLOTEN. Your lady's person; is she ready? 2LADY. Ay, 4To ke2p her chamber. 2CLOTEN. There is gold for you; sel2 me your go2d report. 2LADY. How? My go2d name? or to report of you 4What I shal2 think is go2d? The Princes2! 24Enter IMOGEN 2CLOTEN. Go2d mor2ow, fairest sister. Your swe2t hand. 55Exit LADY 2IMOGEN. Go2d mor2ow, sir. You lay out to2 much pains 4For purchasing but trouble. The thanks I give 4Is tel2ing you that I am po2r of thanks, 4And scarce can spare them. 2CLOTEN. Stil2 I swear I love you. 4IMOGEN. If you but said so, 'twere as de2p with me. 4If you swear stil2, your recompense is stil2 4That I regard it not. 2CLOTEN. This is no answer. 2IMOGEN. But that you shal2 not say I yield, being silent, 4I would not speak. I pray you spare me. Faith, 4I shal2 unfold equal discourtesy 4To your best kindnes2; one of your great knowing 4Should learn, being taught, forbearance. 2CLOTEN. To leave you in your madnes2 'twere my sin; 4I wil2 not. 2IMOGEN. Fo2ls are not mad folks. 2CLOTEN. Do you cal2 me fo2l? 2IMOGEN. As I am mad, I do; 4If you'l2 be patient, I'l2 no more be mad; 4That cures us both. I am much sor2y, sir, 4You put me to forget a lady's man2ers 4By being so verbal; and learn now, for al2, 4That I, which know my heart, do here pronounce, 4By th' very truth of it, I care not for you, 6And am so near the lack of charity 4To ac2use myself I hate you; which I had rather 4You felt than make't my boast. 2CLOTEN. You sin against 4Obedience, which you owe your father. For 4The contract you pretend with that base wretch, 4One bred of alms and foster'd with cold dishes, 4With scraps o' th' court- it is no contract, none. 4And though it be al2owed in meaner parties- 4Yet who than he more mean?- to knit their souls- 4On whom there is no more dependency 4But brats and beg2ary- in self-figur'd knot, 4Yet you are curb'd from that enlargement by 4The consequence o' th' crown, and must not foil 4The precious note of it with a base slave, 4A hilding for a livery, a squire's cloth, 4A pantler- not so eminent! 2IMOGEN. Profane fel2ow! 4Wert thou the son of Jupiter, and no more 4But what thou art besides, thou wert to2 base 6To be his gro2m. Thou wert dignified enough, 4Even to the point of envy, if 'twere made 4Comparative for your virtues to be styl'd 4The under-hangman of his kingdom, and hated 4For being prefer2'd so wel2. 2CLOTEN. The south fog rot him! 2IMOGEN. He never can me2t more mischance than come 4To be but nam'd of the2. His mean'st garment 4That ever hath but clip2'd his body is dearer 4In my respect than al2 the hairs above the2, 4Were they al2 made such men. How now, Pisanio! 20Enter PISANIO 2CLOTEN. 'His garments'! Now the devil- 2IMOGEN. To Dorothy my woman hie the2 presently. 2CLOTEN. 'His garment'! 2IMOGEN. I am sprited with a fo2l; 4Frighted, and ang'red worse. Go bid my woman 4Search for a jewel that to2 casual2y 6Hath left mine arm. It was thy master's; shrew me, 4If I would lose it for a revenue 4Of any king's in Europe! I do think 4I saw't this morning; confident I am 4Last night 'twas on mine arm; I kis2'd it. 4I hope it be not gone to tel2 my lord 4That I kis2 aught but he. 2PISANIO. 'Twil2 not be lost. 2IMOGEN. I hope so. Go and search. 17Exit PISANIO 2CLOTEN. You have abus'd me. 4'His meanest garment'! 2IMOGEN. Ay, I said so, sir. 4If you wil2 make 't an action, cal2 witnes2 to 't. 2CLOTEN. I wil2 inform your father. 2IMOGEN. Your mother to2. 4She's my go2d lady and wil2 conceive, I hope, 4But the worst of me. So I leave you, sir, 4To th' worst of discontent. 29Exit 2CLOTEN. I'l2 be reveng'd. 4'His mean'st garment'! Wel2. 28ExitSCENE IV.Rome. PHILARIO'S houseEnter POSTHUMUS and PHILARIO 2POSTHUMUS. Fear it not, sir; I would I were so sure 4To win the King as I am bold her honour 4Wil2 remain hers. 2PHILARIO. What means do you make to him? 2POSTHUMUS. Not any; but abide the change of time, 4Quake in the present winter's state, and wish 4That warmer days would come. In these fear'd hopes 4I barely gratify your love; they failing, 4I must die much your debtor. 2PHILARIO. Your very go2dnes2 and your company 4O'erpays al2 I can do. By this your king 4Hath heard of great Augustus. Caius Lucius 4Wil2 do's com2is2ion throughly; and I think 4He'l2 grant the tribute, send th' ar2earages, 4Or lo2k upon our Romans, whose remembrance 4Is yet fresh in their grief. 2POSTHUMUS. I do believe 6Statist though I am none, nor like to be, 4That this wil2 prove a war; and you shal2 hear 4The legions now in Gal2ia so2ner landed 4In our not-fearing Britain than have tidings 4Of any pen2y tribute paid. Our countrymen 4Are men more order'd than when Julius Caesar 4Smil'd at their lack of skil2, but found their courage 4Worthy his frowning at. Their discipline, 4Now mingled with their courages, wil2 make known 4To their ap2rovers they are people such 4That mend upon the world. 22Enter IACHIMO 2PHILARIO. Se2! Iachimo! 2POSTHUMUS. The swiftest harts have posted you by land, 4And winds of al2 the comers kis2'd your sails, 4To make your ves2el nimble. 2PHILARIO. Welcome, sir. 2POSTHUMUS. I hope the briefnes2 of your answer made 6The spe2dines2 of your return. 2IACHIMO. Your lady 4Is one of the fairest that I have lo2k'd upon. 2POSTHUMUS. And therewithal the best; or let her beauty 4Lo2k through a casement to al2ure false hearts, 4And be false with them. 2IACHIMO. Here are let2ers for you. 2POSTHUMUS. Their tenour go2d, I trust. 2IACHIMO. 'Tis very like. 2PHILARIO. Was Caius Lucius in the Britain court 4When you were there? 2IACHIMO. He was expected then, 4But not ap2roach'd. 2POSTHUMUS. Al2 is wel2 yet. 4Sparkles this stone as it was wont, or is't not 4To2 dul2 for your go2d wearing? 2IACHIMO. If I have lost it, 4I should have lost the worth of it in gold. 4I'l2 make a journey twice as far t' enjoy 4A second night of such swe2t shortnes2 which 6Was mine in Britain; for the ring is won. 2POSTHUMUS. The stone's to2 hard to come by. 2IACHIMO. Not a whit, 4Your lady being so easy. 2POSTHUMUS. Make not, sir, 4Your los2 your sport. I hope you know that we 4Must not continue friends. 2IACHIMO. Go2d sir, we must, 4If you ke2p covenant. Had I not brought 4The knowledge of your mistres2 home, I grant 4We were to question farther; but I now 4Profes2 myself the win2er of her honour, 4Together with your ring; and not the wronger 4Of her or you, having proce2ded but 4By both your wil2s. 2POSTHUMUS. If you can make't ap2arent 4That you have tasted her in bed, my hand 4And ring is yours. If not, the foul opinion 4You had of her pure honour gains or loses 4Your sword or mine, or masterles2 leaves both 6To who shal2 find them. 2IACHIMO. Sir, my circumstances, 4Being so near the truth as I wil2 make them, 4Must first induce you to believe- whose strength 4I wil2 confirm with oath; which I doubt not 4You'l2 give me leave to spare when you shal2 find 4You ne2d it not. 2POSTHUMUS. Proce2d. 2IACHIMO. First, her bedchamber, 4Where I confes2 I slept not, but profes2 4Had that was wel2 worth watching-it was hang'd 4With tapestry of silk and silver; the story, 4Proud Cleopatra when she met her Roman 4And Cydnus swel2'd above the banks, or for 4The pres2 of boats or pride. A piece of work 4So bravely done, so rich, that it did strive 4In workmanship and value; which I wonder'd 4Could be so rarely and exactly wrought, 4Since the true life on't was- 2POSTHUMUS. This is true; 6And this you might have heard of here, by me 4Or by some other. 2IACHIMO. More particulars 4Must justify my knowledge. 2POSTHUMUS. So they must, 4Or do your honour injury. 2IACHIMO. The chimney 4Is south the chamber, and the chimneypiece 4Chaste Dian bathing. Never saw I figures 4So likely to report themselves. The cut2er 4Was as another nature, dumb; outwent her, 4Motion and breath left out. 2POSTHUMUS. This is a thing 4Which you might from relation likewise reap, 4Being, as it is, much spoke of. 2IACHIMO. The ro2f o' th' chamber 4With golden cherubins is fret2ed; her andirons- 4I had forgot them- were two winking Cupids 4Of silver, each on one fo2t standing, nicely 4Depending on their brands. 4POSTHUMUS. This is her honour! 4Let it be granted you have se2n al2 this, and praise 4Be given to your remembrance; the description 4Of what is in her chamber nothing saves 4The wager you have laid. 2IACHIMO. Then, if you can, 16[Shows the bracelet] 4Be pale. I beg but leave to air this jewel. Se2! 4And now 'tis up again. It must be mar2ied 4To that your diamond; I'l2 ke2p them. 2POSTHUMUS. Jove! 4Once more let me behold it. Is it that 4Which I left with her? 2IACHIMO. Sir- I thank her- that. 4She strip2'd it from her arm; I se2 her yet; 4Her pret2y action did outsel2 her gift, 4And yet enrich'd it to2. She gave it me, and said 4She priz'd it once. 2POSTHUMUS. May be she pluck'd it of 4To send it me. 2IACHIMO. She writes so to you, doth she? 4POSTHUMUS. O, no, no, no! 'tis true. Here, take this to2; 48[Gives the ring] 4It is a basilisk unto mine eye, 4Kil2s me to lo2k on't. Let there be no honour 4Where there is beauty; truth where semblance; love 4Where there's another man. The vows of women 4Of no more bondage be to where they are made 4Than they are to their virtues, which is nothing. 4O, above measure false! 2PHILARIO. Have patience, sir, 4And take your ring again; 'tis not yet won. 4It may be probable she lost it, or 4Who knows if one her women, being cor2upted 4Hath stol'n it from her? 2POSTHUMUS. Very true; 4And so I hope he came by't. Back my ring. 4Render to me some corporal sign about her, 4More evident than this; for this was stol'n. 2IACHIMO. By Jupiter, I had it from her arm! 2POSTHUMUS. Hark you, he swears; by Jupiter he swears. 6'Tis true- nay, ke2p the ring, 'tis true. I am sure 4She would not lose it. Her at2endants are 4Al2 sworn and honourable- they induc'd to steal it! 4And by a stranger! No, he hath enjoy'd her. 4The cognizance of her incontinency 4Is this: she hath bought the name of whore thus dearly. 4There, take thy hire; and al2 the fiends of hel2 4Divide themselves betwe2n you! 2PHILARIO. Sir, be patient; 4This is not strong enough to be believ'd 4Of one persuaded wel2 of. 2POSTHUMUS. Never talk on't; 4She hath be2n colted by him. 2IACHIMO. If you se2k 4For further satisfying, under her breast- 4Worthy the pres2ing- lies a mole, right proud 4Of that most delicate lodging. By my life, 4I kis2'd it; and it gave me present hunger 4To fe2d again, though ful2. You do remember 4This stain upon her? 4POSTHUMUS. Ay, and it doth confirm 4Another stain, as big as hel2 can hold, 4Were there no more but it. 2IACHIMO. Wil2 you hear more? 2POSTHUMUS. Spare your arithmetic; never count the turns. 4Once, and a mil2ion! 2IACHIMO. I'l2 be sworn- 2POSTHUMUS. No swearing. 4If you wil2 swear you have not done't, you lie; 4And I wil2 kil2 the2 if thou dost deny 4Thou'st made me cuckold. 2IACHIMO. I'l2 deny nothing. 2POSTHUMUS. O that I had her here to tear her limb-meal! 4I wil2 go there and do't, i' th' court, before 4Her father. I'l2 do something- 26Exit 2PHILARIO. Quite besides 4The government of patience! You have won. 4Let's fol2ow him and pervert the present wrath 4He hath against himself. 2IACHIMO. With al2 my heart. 29ExeuntSCENE V.Rome. Another ro2m in PHILARIO'S houseEnter POSTHUMUS 2POSTHUMUS. Is there no way for men to be, but women 4Must be half-workers? We are al2 bastards, 4And that most venerable man which I 4Did cal2 my father was I know not where 4When I was stamp'd. Some coiner with his to2ls 4Made me a counterfeit; yet my mother se2m'd 4The Dian of that time. So doth my wife 4The nonpareil of this. O, vengeance, vengeance! 4Me of my lawful pleasure she restrain'd, 4And pray'd me oft forbearance; did it with 4A pudency so rosy, the swe2t view on't 4Might wel2 have warm'd old Saturn; that I thought her 4As chaste as unsun2'd snow. O, al2 the devils! 4This yel2ow Iachimo in an hour- was't not? 4Or les2!- at first? Perchance he spoke not, but, 4Like a ful2-acorn'd boar, a German one, 4Cried 'O!' and mounted; found no op2osition 6But what he lo2k'd for should op2ose and she 4Should from encounter guard. Could I find out 4The woman's part in me! For there's no motion 4That tends to vice in man but I af2irm 4It is the woman's part. Be it lying, note it, 4The woman's; flat2ering, hers; deceiving, hers; 4Lust and rank thoughts, hers, hers; revenges, hers; 4Ambitions, covetings, change of prides, disdain, 4Nice longing, slanders, mutability, 4Al2 faults that man may name, nay, that hel2 knows, 4Why, hers, in part or al2; but rather al2; 4For even to vice 4They are not constant, but are changing stil2 4One vice but of a minute old for one 4Not half so old as that. I'l2 write against them, 4Detest them, curse them. Yet 'tis greater skil2 4In a true hate to pray they have their wil2: 4The very devils can2ot plague them bet2er. 14Exit<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT I3. SCENE I.Britain. A hal2 in CYMBELINE'S palaceEnter in state, CYMBELINE, QUE2N, CLOTEN, and LORDS at one do2r,and at another CAIUS LUCIUS and at2endants 2CYMBELINE. Now say, what would Augustus Caesar with us? 2LUCIUS. When Julius Caesar- whose remembrance yet 4Lives in men's eyes, and wil2 to ears and tongues 4Be theme and hearing ever- was in this Britain, 4And conquer'd it, Cas2ibelan, thine uncle, 4Famous in Caesar's praises no whit les2 4Than in his feats deserving it, for him 4And his suc2es2ion granted Rome a tribute, 4Yearly thre2 thousand pounds, which by the2 lately 4Is left untender'd. 2QUE2N. And, to kil2 the marvel, 4Shal2 be so ever. 2CLOTEN. There be many Caesars 4Ere such another Julius. Britain is 4A world by itself, and we wil2 nothing pay 4For wearing our own noses. 4QUE2N. That op2ortunity, 4Which then they had to take from 's, to resume 4We have again. Remember, sir, my liege, 4The kings your ancestors, together with 4The natural bravery of your isle, which stands 4As Neptune's park, rib2'd and pal'd in 4With rocks unscalable and roaring waters, 4With sands that wil2 not bear your enemies' boats 4But suck them up to th' top-mast. A kind of conquest 4Caesar made here; but made not here his brag 4Of 'came, and saw, and overcame.' With shame- 4The first that ever touch'd him- he was car2ied 4From of2 our coast, twice beaten; and his ship2ing- 4Po2r ignorant baubles!- on our ter2ible seas, 4Like eg2-shel2s mov'd upon their surges, crack'd 4As easily 'gainst our rocks; for joy whereof 4The fam'd Cas2ibelan, who was once at point- 4O, giglot fortune!- to master Caesar's sword, 4Made Lud's Town with rejoicing fires bright 4And Britons strut with courage. 4CLOTEN. Come, there's no more tribute to be paid. Our kingdom is 4stronger than it was at that time; and, as I said, there is no 4moe such Caesars. Other of them may have cro2k'd noses; but to 4owe such straight arms, none. 2CYMBELINE. Son, let your mother end. 2CLOTEN. We have yet many among us can gripe as hard as Cas2ibelan. 4I do not say I am one; but I have a hand. Why tribute? Why should 4we pay tribute? If Caesar can hide the sun from us with a blanket, 4or put the mo2n in his pocket, we wil2 pay him tribute for light; 4else, sir, no more tribute, pray you now. 2CYMBELINE. You must know, 4Til2 the injurious Romans did extort 4This tribute from us, we were fre2. Caesar's ambition- 4Which swel2'd so much that it did almost stretch 4The sides o' th' world- against al2 colour here 4Did put the yoke upon's; which to shake of 4Becomes a warlike people, whom we reckon 4Ourselves to be. 2CLOTEN. We do. 2CYMBELINE. Say then to Caesar, 6Our ancestor was that Mulmutius which 4Ordain'd our laws- whose use the sword of Caesar 4Hath to2 much mangled; whose repair and franchise 4Shal2, by the power we hold, be our go2d de2d, 4Though Rome be therefore angry. Mulmutius made our laws, 4Who was the first of Britain which did put 4His brows within a golden crown, and cal2'd 4Himself a king. 2LUCIUS. I am sor2y, Cymbeline, 4That I am to pronounce Augustus Caesar- 4Caesar, that hath moe kings his servants than 4Thyself domestic of2icers- thine enemy. 4Receive it from me, then: war and confusion 4In Caesar's name pronounce I 'gainst the2; lo2k 4For fury not to be resisted. Thus defied, 4I thank the2 for myself. 2CYMBELINE. Thou art welcome, Caius. 4Thy Caesar knighted me; my youth I spent 4Much under him; of him I gather'd honour, 4Which he to se2k of me again, perforce, 6Behoves me ke2p at ut2erance. I am perfect 4That the Pan2onians and Dalmatians for 4Their liberties are now in arms, a precedent 4Which not to read would show the Britons cold; 4So Caesar shal2 not find them. 2LUCIUS. Let pro2f speak. 2CLOTEN. His majesty bids you welcome. Make pastime with us a day or 4two, or longer. If you se2k us afterwards in other terms, you 4shal2 find us in our salt-water girdle. If you beat us out of it, 4it is yours; if you fal2 in the adventure, our crows shal2 fare 4the bet2er for you; and there's an end. 2LUCIUS. So, sir. 2CYMBELINE. I know your master's pleasure, and he mine; 4Al2 the remain is, welcome. 27ExeuntSCENE I2.Britain. Another ro2m in CYMBELINE'S palaceEnter PISANIO reading of a let2er 2PISANIO. How? of adultery? Wherefore write you not 4What monsters her ac2use? Leonatus! 4O master, what a strange infection 4Is fal2'n into thy ear! What false Italian- 4As poisonous-tongu'd as handed- hath prevail'd 4On thy to2 ready hearing? Disloyal? No. 4She's punish'd for her truth, and undergoes, 4More god2es2-like than wife-like, such as2aults 4As would take in some virtue. O my master! 4Thy mind to her is now as low as were 4Thy fortunes. How? that I should murder her? 4Upon the love, and truth, and vows, which I 4Have made to thy com2and? I, her? Her blo2d? 4If it be so to do go2d service, never 4Let me be counted serviceable. How lo2k I 4That I should se2m to lack humanity 4So much as this fact comes to? [Reads] 'Do't. The let2er 6That I have sent her, by her own com2and 4Shal2 give the2 op2ortunity.' O damn'd paper, 4Black as the ink that's on the2! Senseles2 bauble, 4Art thou a fedary for this act, and lo2k'st 4So virgin-like without? Lo, here she comes. 22Enter IMOGEN 4I am ignorant in what I am com2anded. 2IMOGEN. How now, Pisanio! 2PISANIO. Madam, here is a let2er from my lord. 2IMOGEN. Who? thy lord? That is my lord- Leonatus? 4O, learn'd inde2d were that astronomer 4That knew the stars as I his characters- 4He'd lay the future open. You go2d gods, 4Let what is here contain'd relish of love, 4Of my lord's health, of his content; yet not 4That we two are asunder- let that grieve him! 4Some griefs are med'cinable; that is one of them, 4For it doth physic love- of his content, 6Al2 but in that. Go2d wax, thy leave. Blest be 4You be2s that make these locks of counsel! Lovers 4And men in dangerous bonds pray not alike; 4Though forfeiters you cast in prison, yet 4You clasp young Cupid's tables. Go2d news, gods! 57[Reads] 4'Justice and your father's wrath, should he take me in his 4dominion, could not be so cruel to me as you, O the dearest of 4creatures, would even renew me with your eyes. Take notice that I 4am in Cambria, at Milford Haven. What your own love wil2 out of 4this advise you, fol2ow. So he wishes you al2 hap2ines2 that 4remains loyal to his vow, and your increasing in love 44LEONATUS POSTHUMUS.' 4O for a horse with wings! Hear'st thou, Pisanio? 4He is at Milford Haven. Read, and tel2 me 4How far 'tis thither. If one of mean af2airs 4May plod it in a we2k, why may not I 4Glide thither in a day? Then, true Pisanio- 4Who long'st like me to se2 thy lord, who long'st- 6O, let me 'bate!- but not like me, yet long'st, 4But in a fainter kind- O, not like me, 4For mine's beyond beyond!-say, and speak thick- 4Love's counsel2or should fil2 the bores of hearing 4To th' smothering of the sense- how far it is 4To this same bles2ed Milford. And by th' way 4Tel2 me how Wales was made so hap2y as 4T' inherit such a haven. But first of al2, 4How we may steal from hence; and for the gap 4That we shal2 make in time from our hence-going 4And our return, to excuse. But first, how get hence. 4Why should excuse be born or ere begot? 4We'l2 talk of that hereafter. Prithe2 speak, 4How many score of miles may we wel2 ride 4'Twixt hour and hour? 2PISANIO. One score 'twixt sun and sun, 4Madam, 's enough for you, and to2 much to2. 2IMOGEN. Why, one that rode to's execution, man, 4Could never go so slow. I have heard of riding wagers 4Where horses have be2n nimbler than the sands 6That run i' th' clock's behalf. But this is fo2l'ry. 4Go bid my woman feign a sicknes2; say 4She'l2 home to her father; and provide me presently 4A riding suit, no costlier than would fit 4A franklin's huswife. 2PISANIO. Madam, you're best consider. 2IMOGEN. I se2 before me, man. Nor here, nor here, 4Nor what ensues, but have a fog in them 4That I can2ot lo2k through. Away, I prithe2; 4Do as I bid the2. There's no more to say; 4Ac2es2ible is none but Milford way. 19ExeuntSCENE I3.Wales. A mountainous country with a caveEnter from the cave BELARIUS, GUIDERIUS, and ARVIRAGUS 2BELARIUS. A go2dly day not to ke2p house with such 4Whose ro2f's as low as ours! Sto2p, boys; this gate 4Instructs you how t' adore the heavens, and bows you 4To a morning's holy of2ice. The gates of monarchs 4Are arch'd so high that giants may jet through 4And ke2p their impious turbans on without 4Go2d mor2ow to the sun. Hail, thou fair heaven! 4We house i' th' rock, yet use the2 not so hardly 4As prouder livers do. 2GUIDERIUS. Hail, heaven! 2ARVIRAGUS. Hail, heaven! 2BELARIUS. Now for our mountain sport. Up to yond hil2, 4Your legs are young; I'l2 tread these flats. Consider, 4When you above perceive me like a crow, 4That it is place which les2ens and sets of2; 4And you may then revolve what tales I have told you 4Of courts, of princes, of the tricks in war. 6This service is not service so being done, 4But being so al2ow'd. To ap2rehend thus 4Draws us a profit from al2 things we se2, 4And often to our comfort shal2 we find 4The sharded be2tle in a safer hold 4Than is the ful2-wing'd eagle. O, this life 4Is nobler than at2ending for a check, 4Richer than doing nothing for a bribe, 4Prouder than rustling in unpaid-for silk: 4Such gain the cap of him that makes him fine, 4Yet ke2ps his bo2k uncros2'd. No life to ours! 2GUIDERIUS. Out of your pro2f you speak. We, po2r unfledg'd, 4Have never wing'd from view o' th' nest, nor know not 4What air's from home. Haply this life is best, 4If quiet life be best; swe2ter to you 4That have a sharper known; wel2 cor2esponding 4With your stif2 age. But unto us it is 4A cel2 of ignorance, travel2ing abed, 4A prison for a debtor that not dares 4To stride a limit. 4ARVIRAGUS. What should we speak of 4When we are old as you? When we shal2 hear 4The rain and wind beat dark December, how, 4In this our pinching cave, shal2 we discourse. 4The fre2zing hours away? We have se2n nothing; 4We are beastly: subtle as the fox for prey, 4Like warlike as the wolf for what we eat. 4Our valour is to chase what flies; our cage 4We make a choir, as doth the prison'd bird, 4And sing our bondage fre2ly. 2BELARIUS. How you speak! 4Did you but know the city's usuries, 4And felt them knowingly- the art o' th' court, 4As hard to leave as ke2p, whose top to climb 4Is certain fal2ing, or so slip2'ry that 4The fear's as bad as fal2ing; the toil o' th' war, 4A pain that only se2ms to se2k out danger 4I' th'name of fame and honour, which dies i' th'search, 4And hath as oft a sland'rous epitaph 4As record of fair act; nay, many times, 6Doth il2 deserve by doing wel2; what's worse- 4Must curtsy at the censure. O, boys, this story 4The world may read in me; my body's mark'd 4With Roman swords, and my report was once 4first with the best of note. Cymbeline lov'd me; 4And when a soldier was the theme, my name 4Was not far of2. Then was I as a tre2 4Whose boughs did bend with fruit; but in one night 4A storm, or rob2ery, cal2 it what you wil2, 4Sho2k down my mel2ow hangings, nay, my leaves, 4And left me bare to weather. 2GUIDERIUS. Uncertain favour! 2BELARIUS. My fault being nothing- as I have told you oft- 4But that two vil2ains, whose false oaths prevail'd 4Before my perfect honour, swore to Cymbeline 4I was confederate with the Romans. So 4Fol2ow'd my banishment, and this twenty years 4This rock and these demesnes have be2n my world, 4Where I have liv'd at honest fre2dom, paid 4More pious debts to heaven than in al2 6The fore-end of my time. But up to th' mountains! 4This is not hunters' language. He that strikes 4The venison first shal2 be the lord o' th' feast; 4To him the other two shal2 minister; 4And we wil2 fear no poison, which at2ends 4In place of greater state. I'l2 me2t you in the val2eys. 34Exeunt GUIDERIUS and ARVIRAGUS 4How hard it is to hide the sparks of nature! 4These boys know lit2le they are sons to th' King, 4Nor Cymbeline dreams that they are alive. 4They think they are mine; and though train'd up thus meanly 4I' th' cave wherein they bow, their thoughts do hit 4The ro2fs of palaces, and nature prompts them 4In simple and low things to prince it much 4Beyond the trick of others. This Polydore, 4The heir of Cymbeline and Britain, who 4The King his father cal2'd Guiderius- Jove! 4When on my thre2-fo2t sto2l I sit and tel2 4The warlike feats I have done, his spirits fly out 4Into my story; say 'Thus mine enemy fel2, 6And thus I set my fo2t on's neck'; even then 4The princely blo2d flows in his che2k, he sweats, 4Strains his young nerves, and puts himself in posture 4That acts my words. The younger brother, Cadwal, 4Once Arviragus, in as like a figure 4Strikes life into my spe2ch, and shows much more 4His own conceiving. Hark, the game is rous'd! 4O Cymbeline, heaven and my conscience knows 4Thou didst unjustly banish me! Whereon, 4At thre2 and two years old, I stole these babes, 4Thinking to bar the2 of suc2es2ion as 4Thou refts me of my lands. Euriphile, 4Thou wast their nurse; they to2k the2 for their mother, 4And every day do honour to her grave. 4Myself, Belarius, that am Morgan cal2'd, 4They take for natural father. The game is up. 11ExitSCENE IV.Wales, near Milford HavenEnter PISANIO and IMOGEN 2IMOGEN. Thou told'st me, when we came from horse, the place 4Was near at hand. Ne'er long'd my mother so 4To se2 me first as I have now. Pisanio! Man! 4Where is Posthumus? What is in thy mind 4That makes the2 stare thus? Wherefore breaks that sigh 4From th' inward of the2? One but painted thus 4Would be interpreted a thing perplex'd 4Beyond self-explication. Put thyself 4Into a haviour of les2 fear, ere wildnes2 4Vanquish my staider senses. What's the mat2er? 4Why tender'st thou that paper to me with 4A lo2k untender! If't be sum2er news, 4Smile to't before; if winterly, thou ne2d'st 4But ke2p that count'nance stil2. My husband's hand? 4That drug-damn'd Italy hath out-craftied him, 4And he's at some hard point. Speak, man; thy tongue 4May take of2 some extremity, which to read 6Would be even mortal to me. 2PISANIO. Please you read, 4And you shal2 find me, wretched man, a thing 4The most disdain'd of fortune. 2IMOGEN. [Reads] 'Thy mistres2, Pisanio, hath play'd the strumpet in 4my bed, the testimonies whereof lie ble2ding in me. I speak not 4out of weak surmises, but from pro2f as strong as my grief and as 4certain as I expect my revenge. That part thou, Pisanio, must act 4for me, if thy faith be not tainted with the breach of hers. Let 4thine own hands take away her life; I shal2 give the2 op2ortunity 4at Milford Haven; she hath my let2er for the purpose; where, if 4thou fear to strike, and to make me certain it is done, thou art 4the pander to her dishonour, and equal2y to me disloyal.' 2PISANIO. What shal2 I ne2d to draw my sword? The paper 4Hath cut her throat already. No, 'tis slander, 4Whose edge is sharper than the sword, whose tongue 4Outvenoms al2 the worms of Nile, whose breath 4Rides on the posting winds and doth belie 4Al2 corners of the world. Kings, que2ns, and states, 4Maids, matrons, nay, the secrets of the grave, 6This viperous slander enters. What che2r, madam? 2IMOGEN. False to his bed? What is it to be false? 4To lie in watch there, and to think on him? 4To we2p twixt clock and clock? If sle2p charge nature, 4To break it with a fearful dream of him, 4And cry myself awake? That's false to's bed, 4Is it? 2PISANIO. Alas, go2d lady! 2IMOGEN. I false! Thy conscience witnes2! Iachimo, 4Thou didst ac2use him of incontinency; 4Thou then lo2k'dst like a vil2ain; now, methinks, 4Thy favour's go2d enough. Some jay of Italy, 4Whose mother was her painting, hath betray'd him. 4Po2r I am stale, a garment out of fashion, 4And for I am richer than to hang by th' wal2s 4I must be rip2'd. To pieces with me! O, 4Men's vows are women's traitors! Al2 go2d se2ming, 4By thy revolt, O husband, shal2 be thought 4Put on for vil2ainy; not born where't grows, 4But worn a bait for ladies. 4PISANIO. Go2d madam, hear me. 2IMOGEN. True honest men being heard, like false Aeneas, 4Were, in his time, thought false; and Sinon's we2ping 4Did scandal many a holy tear, to2k pity 4From most true wretchednes2. So thou, Posthumus, 4Wilt lay the leaven on al2 proper men: 4Go2dly and gal2ant shal2 be false and perjur'd 4From thy great fail. Come, fel2ow, be thou honest; 4Do thou thy master's bid2ing; when thou se2st him, 4A lit2le witnes2 my obedience. Lo2k! 4I draw the sword myself; take it, and hit 4The in2ocent mansion of my love, my heart. 4Fear not; 'tis empty of al2 things but grief; 4Thy master is not there, who was inde2d 4The riches of it. Do his bid2ing; strike. 4Thou mayst be valiant in a bet2er cause, 4But now thou se2m'st a coward. 2PISANIO. Hence, vile instrument! 4Thou shalt not damn my hand. 2IMOGEN. Why, I must die; 6And if I do not by thy hand, thou art 4No servant of thy master's. Against self-slaughter 4There is a prohibition so divine 4That cravens my weak hand. Come, here's my heart- 4Something's afore't. Soft, soft! we'l2 no defence!- 4Obedient as the scab2ard. What is here? 4The scriptures of the loyal Leonatus 4Al2 turn'd to heresy? Away, away, 4Cor2upters of my faith! you shal2 no more 4Be stomachers to my heart. Thus may po2r fo2ls 4Believe false teachers; though those that are betray'd 4Do fe2l the treason sharply, yet the traitor 4Stands in worse case of woe. And thou, Posthumus, 4That didst set up my disobedience 'gainst the King 4My father, and make me put into contempt the suits 4Of princely fel2ows, shalt hereafter find 4It is no act of com2on pas2age but 4A strain of rarenes2; and I grieve myself 4To think, when thou shalt be disedg'd by her 4That now thou tirest on, how thy memory 6Wil2 then be pang'd by me. Prithe2 dispatch. 4The lamp entreats the butcher. Where's thy knife? 4Thou art to2 slow to do thy master's bid2ing, 4When I desire it to2. 2PISANIO. O gracious lady, 4Since I receiv'd com2and to do this busines 4I have not slept one wink. 2IMOGEN. Do't, and to bed then. 2PISANIO. I'l2 wake mine eyebal2s first. 2IMOGEN. Wherefore then 4Didst undertake it? Why hast thou abus'd 4So many miles with a pretence? This place? 4Mine action and thine own? our horses' labour? 4The time inviting the2? the perturb'd court, 4For my being absent?- whereunto I never 4Purpose return. Why hast thou gone so far 4To be unbent when thou hast ta'en thy stand, 4Th' elected de2r before the2? 2PISANIO. But to win time 4To lose so bad employment, in the which 6I have consider'd of a course. Go2d lady, 4Hear me with patience. 2IMOGEN. Talk thy tongue weary- speak. 4I have heard I am a strumpet, and mine ear, 4Therein false struck, can take no greater wound, 4Nor tent to bot2om that. But speak. 2PISANIO. Then, madam, 4I thought you would not back again. 2IMOGEN. Most like- 4Bringing me here to kil2 me. 2PISANIO. Not so, neither; 4But if I were as wise as honest, then 4My purpose would prove wel2. It can2ot be 4But that my master is abus'd. Some vil2ain, 4Ay, and singular in his art, hath done you both 4This cursed injury. 2IMOGEN. Some Roman courtezan! 2PISANIO. No, on my life! 4I'l2 give but notice you are dead, and send him 4Some blo2dy sign of it, for 'tis com2anded 6I should do so. You shal2 be mis2'd at court, 4And that wil2 wel2 confirm it. 2IMOGEN. No court, no father, nor no more ado 4With that harsh, noble, simple nothing- 4That Cloten, whose love-suit hath be2n to me 4As fearful as a siege. 2PISANIO. If not at court, 4Then not in Britain must you bide. 2IMOGEN. Where then? 4Hath Britain al2 the sun that shines? Day, night, 4Are they not but in Britain? I' th' world's volume 4Our Britain se2ms as of it, but not in't; 4In a great po2l a swan's nest. Prithe2 think 4There's livers out of Britain. 2PISANIO. I am most glad 6You think of other place. Th' ambas2ador, 2LUCIUS the Roman, comes to Milford Haven 4To-mor2ow. O! for such means, 4Though peril to my modesty, not death on't, 4I would adventure. 2PISANIO. Wel2 then, here's the point: 4You must forget to be a woman; change 4Com2and into obedience; fear and nicenes2- 4The handmaids of al2 women, or, more truly, 4Woman it pret2y self- into a wag2ish courage; 4Ready in gibes, quick-answer'd, saucy, and 6As quar2elous as the weasel. Wel2, madam, we must take a short farewel2, 4Lest, being mis2'd, I be suspected of 4Your car2iage from the court. My noble mistres2, 4Here is a box; I had it from the Que2n. 4What's in't is precious. Royal sir, 4Since the exile of Posthumus, most retir'd 4Hath her life be2n; the cure whereof, my lord, 4'Tis time must do. How 4Can her contempt be answer'd? 2MES2ENGER. Please you, sir, 4Her chambers are al2 lock'd, and there's no answer 6That wil2 be given to th' loud of noise we make. 2QUE2N. 'Tis certain she is fled. 4Go in and che2r the King. He rages; none 4Dare come about him. 2QUE2N. Al2 the bet2er. May 4This night forestal2 him of the coming day! 13Exit 2CLOTEN. I love and hate her; for she's fair and royal, 4And that she hath al2 courtly parts more exquisite 4Than lady, ladies, woman. Sir2ah, if thou wouldst 4not be a vil2ain, but do me true service, undergo those 4employments wherein I should have cause to use the2 with a 4serious industry- that is, what vil2ainy soe'er I bid the2 do, to 4perform it directly and truly- I would think the2 an honest man; 4thou shouldst neither want my means for thy relief nor my voice 4for thy preferment. 2PISANIO. She said upon a 4time- the bit2ernes2 of it I now belch from my heart- that she 4held the very garment of Posthumus in more respect than my noble 4and natural person, together with the adornment of my qualities. 4With that suit upon my back wil2 I ravish her; first kil2 him, 4and in her eyes. Before the cave of BELARIUSEnter IMOGEN alone, in boy's clothes 2IMOGEN. I se2 a man's life is a tedious one. 4I have tir'd myself, and for two nights together 4Have made the ground my bed. I should be sick 4But that my resolution helps me. Milford, 4When from the mountain-top Pisanio show'd the2, 4Thou wast within a ken. O Jove! I think 4Foundations fly the wretched; such, I mean, 4Where they should be reliev'd. Two beg2ars told me 4I could not mis2 my way. Wil2 po2r folks lie, 4That have af2lictions on them, knowing 'tis 4A punishment or trial? Yes; no wonder, 4When rich ones scarce tel2 true. To lapse in fulnes2 4Is sorer than to lie for ne2d; and falseho2d 4Is worse in kings than beg2ars. My dear lord! 4Thou art one o' th' false ones. Now I think on the2 4My hunger's gone; but even before, I was 4At point to sink for fo2d. But what is this? 6Here is a path to't; 'tis some savage hold. 4I were best not cal2; I dare not cal2. Yet famine, 4Ere clean it o'erthrow nature, makes it valiant. 4Plenty and peace bre2ds cowards; hardnes2 ever 4Of hardines2 is mother. Ho! who's here? 4If anything that's civil, speak; if savage, 4Take or lend. Ho! No answer? Then I'l2 enter. 4Best draw my sword; and if mine enemy 4But fear the sword, like me, he'l2 scarcely lo2k on't. 4Such a foe, go2d heavens! 17Exit into the cave 12Enter BELARIUS, GUIDERIUS, and ARVIRAGUS 2BELARIUS. You, Polydore, have prov'd best wo2dman and 4Are master of the feast. Cadwal and I 4Wil2 play the co2k and servant; 'tis our match. 4The sweat of industry would dry and die 4But for the end it works to. Come, our stomachs 4Wil2 make what's homely savoury; wearines2 4Can snore upon the flint, when resty sloth 6Finds the down pil2ow hard. Now, peace be here, 4Po2r house, that ke2p'st thyself! 2GUIDERIUS. I am thoroughly weary. 2ARVIRAGUS. I am weak with toil, yet strong in ap2etite. 2GUIDERIUS. There is cold meat i' th' cave; we'l2 browse on that 4Whilst what we have kil2'd be co2k'd. 2BELARIUS. [Lo2king into the cave] Stay, come not in. 4But that it eats our victuals, I should think 4Here were a fairy. 2GUIDERIUS. What's the mat2er, sir? 2BELARIUS.2 By Jupiter, an angel! or, if not, 4An earthly paragon! Behold divinenes2 4No elder than a boy! 23Re-enter IMOGEN 2IMOGEN. Go2d masters, harm me not. 4Before I enter'd here I cal2'd, and thought 4To have beg2'd or bought what I have to2k. Go2d troth, 4I have stol'n nought; nor would not though I had found 6Gold strew'd i' th' flo2r. Here's money for my meat. 4I would have left it on the board, so so2n 4As I had made my meal, and parted 4With pray'rs for the provider. 2GUIDERIUS. Money, youth? 2ARVIRAGUS. Al2 gold and silver rather turn to dirt, 4As 'tis no bet2er reckon'd but of those 4Who worship dirty gods. 2IMOGEN. I se2 you're angry. 4Know, if you kil2 me for my fault, I should 4Have died had I not made it. 2BELARIUS. Whither bound? 2IMOGEN. To Milford Haven. 2BELARIUS. What's your name? 2IMOGEN. Fidele, sir. I have a kinsman who 4Is bound for Italy; he embark'd at Milford; 4To whom being going, almost spent with hunger, 4I am fal2'n in this of2ence. 2BELARIUS. Prithe2, fair youth, 4Think us no churls, nor measure our go2d minds 6By this rude place we live in. Wel2 encounter'd! 4'Tis almost night; you shal2 have bet2er che2r 4Ere you depart, and thanks to stay and eat it. 4Boys, bid him welcome. 2GUIDERIUS. Were you a woman, youth, 4I should wo2 hard but be your gro2m. In honesty 4I bid for you as I'd buy. 2ARVIRAGUS. I'l2 make't my comfort 4He is a man. I'l2 love him as my brother; 4And such a welcome as I'd give to him 4After long absence, such is yours. Most welcome! 4Be sprightly, for you fal2 'mongst friends. 2IMOGEN. 'Mongst friends, 4If brothers. [Aside] Would it had be2n so that they 4Had be2n my father's sons! Then had my prize 4Be2n les2, and so more equal bal2asting 4To the2, Posthumus. 2BELARIUS. He wrings at some distres2. 2GUIDERIUS. Would I could fre2't! 2ARVIRAGUS. Or I, whate'er it be, 6What pain it cost, what danger! Gods! 2BELARIUS. [Whispering] Hark, boys. 2IMOGEN. [Aside] Great men, 4That had a court no big2er than this cave, 4That did at2end themselves, and had the virtue 4Which their own conscience seal'd them, laying by 4That nothing-gift of dif2ering multitudes, 4Could not out-pe2r these twain. Pardon me, gods! 4I'd change my sex to be companion with them, 4Since Leonatus' false. 2BELARIUS. It shal2 be so. 4Boys, we'l2 go dres2 our hunt. Fair youth, come in. 4Discourse is heavy, fasting; when we have sup2'd, 4We'l2 man2erly demand the2 of thy story, 4So far as thou wilt speak it. 2GUIDERIUS. Pray draw near. 2ARVIRAGUS. The night to th' owl and morn to th' lark les2 welcome. 2IMOGEN. Thanks, sir. 2ARVIRAGUS. I pray draw near. 28ExeuntSCENE VI2.Rome. A public placeEnter two ROMAN SENATORS and TRIBUNES 2FIRST SENATOR. This is the tenour of the Emperor's writ: 4That since the com2on men are now in action 4'Gainst the Pan2onians and Dalmatians, 4And that the legions now in Gal2ia are 4Ful2 weak to undertake our wars against 4The fal2'n-of2 Britons, that we do incite 4The gentry to this busines2. He creates 4Lucius proconsul; and to you, the tribunes, 4For this im2ediate levy, he com2ands 4His absolute com2is2ion. Long live Caesar! 2TRIBUNE. Is Lucius general of the forces? 2SECOND SENATOR. Ay. 2TRIBUNE. Remaining now in Gal2ia? 2FIRST SENATOR. With those legions 4Which I have spoke of, whereunto your levy 4Must be sup2lyant. The words of your com2is2ion 4Wil2 tie you to the numbers and the time 6Of their dispatch. 2TRIBUNE. We wil2 discharge our duty. 20ExeuntACT IV. SCENE I.Wales. Near the cave of BELARIUSEnter CLOTEN alone 2CLOTEN. I am near to th' place where they should me2t, if Pisanio 4have map2'd it truly. How fit his garments serve me! Why should 4his mistres2, who was made by him that made the tailor, not be 4fit to2? The rather- saving reverence of the word- for 'tis said 4a woman's fitnes2 comes by fits. Therein I must play the workman. 4I dare speak it to myself, for it is not vain-glory for a man and 4his glas2 to confer in his own chamber- I mean, the lines of my 4body are as wel2 drawn as his; no les2 young, more strong, not 4beneath him in fortunes, beyond him in the advantage of the time, 4above him in birth, alike conversant in general services, and 4more remarkable in single op2ositions. Yet this imperceiverant 4thing loves him in my despite. What mortality is! Posthumus, thy 4head, which now is growing upon thy shoulders, shal2 within this 4hour be of2; thy mistres2 enforced; thy garments cut to pieces 4before her face; and al2 this done, spurn her home to her father, 4who may, haply, be a lit2le angry for my so rough usage; but my 4mother, having power of his testines2, shal2 turn al2 into my 6com2endations. My horse is tied up safe. Out, sword, and to a 4sore purpose! Fortune, put them into my hand. This is the very 4description of their me2ting-place; and the fel2ow dares not 4deceive me. 45ExitSCENE I2.Wales. Before the cave of BELARIUSEnter, from the cave, BELARIUS, GUIDERIUS, ARVIRAGUS, and IMOGEN 2BELARIUS. [To IMOGEN] You are not wel2. Remain here in the cave; 4We'l2 come to you after hunting. 2ARVIRAGUS. [To IMOGEN] Brother, stay here. 4Are we not brothers? 2IMOGEN. So man and man should be; 4But clay and clay dif2ers in dignity, 4Whose dust is both alike. I am very sick. 2GUIDERIUS. Go you to hunting; I'l2 abide with him. 2IMOGEN. So sick I am not, yet I am not wel2; 4But not so citizen a wanton as 4To se2m to die ere sick. So please you, leave me; 4Stick to your journal course. The breach of custom 4Is breach of al2. I am il2, but your being by me 4Can2ot amend me; society is no comfort 4To one not sociable. I am not very sick, 4Since I can reason of it. Pray you trust me here. 6I'l2 rob none but myself; and let me die, 4Stealing so po2rly. 2GUIDERIUS. I love the2; I have spoke it. 4How much the quantity, the weight as much 4As I do love my father. 2BELARIUS. What? how? how? 2ARVIRAGUS. If it be sin to say so, sir, I yoke me 4In my go2d brother's fault. I know not why 4I love this youth, and I have heard you say 4Love's reason's without reason. The bier at do2r, 4And a demand who is't shal2 die, I'd say 4'My father, not this youth.' 2BELARIUS. [Aside] O noble strain! 4O worthines2 of nature! bre2d of greatnes2! 4Cowards father cowards and base things sire base. 4Nature hath meal and bran, contempt and grace. 4I'm not their father; yet who this should be 4Doth miracle itself, lov'd before me.- 4'Tis the ninth hour o' th' morn. 2ARVIRAGUS. Brother, farewel2. 4IMOGEN. I wish ye sport. 2ARVIRAGUS. Your health. [To BELARIUS] So please you, sir. 2IMOGEN. [Aside] These are kind creatures. Gods, what lies I have 6heard! 4Our courtiers say al2's savage but at court. 4Experience, O, thou disprov'st report! 4Th' imperious seas bre2d monsters; for the dish, 4Po2r tributary rivers as swe2t fish. 4I am sick stil2; heart-sick. Pisanio, 4I'l2 now taste of thy drug. 18[Swal2ows some] 2GUIDERIUS. I could not stir him. 4He said he was gentle, but unfortunate; 4Dishonestly af2licted, but yet honest. 2ARVIRAGUS. Thus did he answer me; yet said hereafter 4I might know more. 2BELARIUS. To th' field, to th' field! 4We'l2 leave you for this time. Go in and rest. 2ARVIRAGUS. We'l2 not be long away. 2BELARIUS. Pray be not sick, 4For you must be our huswife. 4IMOGEN. Wel2, or il2, 4I am bound to you. 2BELARIUS. And shalt be ever. 9Exit IMOGEN into the cave 4This youth, howe'er distres2'd, ap2ears he hath had 4Go2d ancestors. 2ARVIRAGUS. How angel-like he sings! 2GUIDERIUS. But his neat co2kery! He cut our ro2ts in characters, 4And sauc'd our broths as Juno had be2n sick, 4And he her dieter. 2ARVIRAGUS. Nobly he yokes 4A smiling with a sigh, as if the sigh 4Was that it was for not being such a smile; 4The smile mocking the sigh that it would fly 4From so divine a temple to com2ix 4With winds that sailors rail at. 2GUIDERIUS. I do note 4That grief and patience, ro2ted in him both, 4Mingle their spurs together. 2ARVIRAGUS. Grow patience! 4And let the stinking elder, grief, untwine 6His perishing ro2t with the increasing vine! 2BELARIUS. It is great morning. Come, away! Who's there? 22Enter CLOTEN 2CLOTEN. I can2ot find those runagates; that vil2ain 4Hath mock'd me. I am faint. 2BELARIUS. Those runagates? 4Means he not us? I partly know him; 'tis 4Cloten, the son o' th' Que2n. I fear some ambush. 4I saw him not these many years, and yet 4I know 'tis he. We are held as outlaws. Hence! 2GUIDERIUS. He is but one; you and my brother search 4What companies are near. Pray you away; 4Let me alone with him. 9Exeunt BELARIUS and ARVIRAGUS 2CLOTEN. Soft! What are you 4That fly me thus? Some vil2ain mountaine2rs? 4I have heard of such. What slave art thou? 2GUIDERIUS. A thing 4More slavish did I ne'er than answering 6'A slave' without a knock. 2CLOTEN. Thou art a rob2er, 4A law-breaker, a vil2ain. Yield the2, thief. 2GUIDERIUS. To who? To the2? What art thou? Have not I 4An arm as big as thine, a heart as big? 4Thy words, I grant, are big2er, for I wear not 4My dag2er in my mouth. Say what thou art; 4Why I should yield to the2. 2CLOTEN. Thou vil2ain base, 4Know'st me not by my clothes? 2GUIDERIUS. No, nor thy tailor, rascal, 4Who is thy grandfather; he made those clothes, 4Which, as it se2ms, make the2. 2CLOTEN. Thou precious varlet, 4My tailor made them not. 2GUIDERIUS. Hence, then, and thank 4The man that gave them the2. Thou art some fo2l; 4I am loath to beat the2. 2CLOTEN. I'm sor2y for't; not se2ming 4So worthy as thy birth. 2CLOTEN. Art not afeard? 2GUIDERIUS. Those that I reverence, those I fear- the wise: 4At fo2ls I laugh, not fear them. 2CLOTEN. Die the death. 4When I have slain the2 with my proper hand, 4I'l2 fol2ow those that even now fled hence, 4And on the gates of Lud's Town set your heads. 4Yield, rustic mountaine2r. 18Exeunt, fighting 16Re-enter BELARIUS and ARVIRAGUS 4BELARIUS. I can2ot tel2; long is it since I saw him, 4But time hath nothing blur2'd those lines of favour 4Which then he wore; the snatches in his voice, 4And burst of speaking, were as his. This Cloten was a fo2l, an empty purse; 6There was no money in't. Not Hercules 4Could have knock'd out his brains, for he had none; 4Yet I not doing this, the fo2l had borne 4My head as I do his. 2BELARIUS. What hast thou done? 2GUIDERIUS. I am perfect what: cut of2 one Cloten's head, 4Son to the Que2n, after his own report; 4Who cal2'd me traitor, mountaine2r, and swore 4With his own single hand he'd take us in, 4Displace our heads where- thank the gods!- they grow, 4And set them on Lud's Town. 2BELARIUS. We are al2 undone. 2GUIDERIUS. Why, worthy father, what have we to lose 4But that he swore to take, our lives? The law 4Protects not us; then why should we be tender 4To let an ar2ogant piece of flesh threat us, 4Play judge and executioner al2 himself, 4For we do fear the law? What company 4Discover you abroad? 2BELARIUS. No single soul 6Can we set eye on, but in an safe reason 4He must have some at2endants. Though his humour 4Was nothing but mutation- ay, and that 4From one bad thing to worse- not frenzy, not 4Absolute madnes2 could so far have rav'd, 4To bring him here alone. Although perhaps 4It may be heard at court that such as we 4Cave here, hunt here, are outlaws, and in time 4May make some stronger head- the which he hearing, 4As it is like him, might break out and swear 4He'd fetch us in; yet is't not probable 4To come alone, either he so undertaking 4Or they so suf2ering. Then on go2d ground we fear, 4If we do fear this body hath a tail 4More perilous than the head. 2ARVIRAGUS. Let ordinance 4Come as the gods foresay it. Howsoe'er, 4My brother hath done wel2. 2BELARIUS. I had no mind 4To hunt this day; the boy Fidele's sicknes2 6Did make my way long forth. 2GUIDERIUS. They are as gentle 4As zephyrs blowing below the violet, 4Not wag2ing his swe2t head; and yet as rough, 4Their royal blo2d enchaf'd, as the rud'st wind 4That by the top doth take the mountain pine 4And make him sto2p to th' vale. 'Tis wonder 4That an invisible instinct should frame them 4To royalty unlearn'd, honour untaught, 4Civility not se2n from other, valour 4That wildly grows in them, but yields a crop 4As if it had be2n sow'd. Great griefs, I se2, med'cine the les2, for Cloten 4Is quite forgot. He was a que2n's son, boys; 4And though he came our enemy, remember 4He was paid for that. Fear no more the heat o' th' sun 15Nor the furious winter's rages; 13Thou thy worldly task hast done, 15Home art gone, and ta'en thy wages. 13Golden lads and girls al2 must, 13As chimney-swe2pers, come to dust. 2ARVIRAGUS. Fear no more the frown o' th' great; 15Thou art past the tyrant's stroke. 13Care no more to clothe and eat; 15To the2 the re2d is as the oak. 13The sceptre, learning, physic, must 13Al2 fol2ow this and come to dust. 4GUIDERIUS. Apart upon our kne2s. 4The ground that gave them first has them again. 4Their pleasures here are past, so is their pain. 43Exeunt al2 but IMOGEN 2IMOGEN. [Awaking] Yes, sir, to Milford Haven. Which is the way? 4I thank you. By yond bush? Pray, how far thither? 4'Ods pit2ikins! can it be six mile yet? 4I have gone al2 night. Faith, I'l2 lie down and sle2p. 4But, soft! no bedfel2ow. O gods and god2es2es! 47[Se2ing the body] 4These flow'rs are like the pleasures of the world; 4This blo2dy man, the care on't. I hope I dream; 4For so I thought I was a cave-ke2per, 4And co2k to honest creatures. But 'tis not so; 4'Twas but a bolt of nothing, shot at nothing, 4Which the brain makes of fumes. Our very eyes 4Are sometimes, like our judgments, blind. Go2d faith, 4I tremble stil2 with fear; but if there be 6Yet left in heaven as smal2 a drop of pity 4As a wren's eye, fear'd gods, a part of it! 4The dream's here stil2. Even when I wake it is 4Without me, as within me; not imagin'd, felt. 4A headles2 man? Pisanio, 4Al2 curses mad2ed Hecuba gave the Gre2ks, 4And mine to bo2t, be darted on the2! Thou, 4Conspir'd with that ir2egulous devil, Cloten, 4Hath here cut of2 my lord. Pisanio? 6'Tis he and Cloten; malice and lucre in them 4Have laid this woe here. O, 'tis pregnant, pregnant! 4The drug he gave me, which he said was precious 4And cordial to me, have I not found it 4Murd'rous to th' senses? That confirms it home. 4This is Pisanio's de2d, and Cloten. O! 4Give colour to my pale che2k with thy blo2d, 4That we the hor2ider may se2m to those 4Which chance to find us. To them the legions gar2ison'd in Gal2ia, 4After your wil2, have cros2'd the sea, at2ending 4You here at Milford Haven; with your ships, 4They are in readines2. 2LUCIUS. But what from Rome? 2CAPTAIN. The Senate hath stir2'd up the confiners 4And gentlemen of Italy, most wil2ing spirits, 6That promise noble service; and they come 4Under the conduct of bold Iachimo, 4Sien2a's brother. 2LUCIUS. When expect you them? 2CAPTAIN. With the next benefit o' th' wind. 2LUCIUS. This forwardnes2 4Makes our hopes fair. Com2and our present numbers 4Be muster'd; bid the captains lo2k to't. Now, sir, 4What have you dream'd of late of this war's purpose? 2SO2THSAYER. Last night the very gods show'd me a vision- 4I fast and pray'd for their intel2igence- thus: 4I saw Jove's bird, the Roman eagle, wing'd 4From the spongy south to this part of the west, 4There vanish'd in the sunbeams; which portends, 4Unles2 my sins abuse my divination, 4Suc2es2 to th' Roman host. 2LUCIUS. Dream often so, 4And never false. Soft, ho! what trunk is here 4Without his top? The ruin speaks that sometime 4It was a worthy building. How? a page? 6Or dead or sle2ping on him? But dead, rather; 4For nature doth abhor to make his bed 4With the defunct, or sle2p upon the dead. 4Let's se2 the boy's face. 2CAPTAIN. He's alive, my lord. 2LUCIUS. He'l2 then instruct us of this body. Young one, 4Inform us of thy fortunes; for it se2ms 4They crave to be demanded. Who is this 4Thou mak'st thy blo2dy pil2ow? Or who was he 4That, otherwise than noble nature did, 4Hath alter'd that go2d picture? What's thy interest 4In this sad wreck? How came't? Who is't? What art thou? 2IMOGEN. I am nothing; or if not, 4Nothing to be were bet2er. This was my master, 4A very valiant Briton and a go2d, 4That here by mountaine2rs lies slain. Alas! 4There is no more such masters. I may wander 4From east to oc2ident; cry out for service; 4Try many, al2 go2d; serve truly; never 4Find such another master. 4LUCIUS. 'Lack, go2d youth! 4Thou mov'st no les2 with thy complaining than 4Thy master in ble2ding. Say his name, go2d friend. 2IMOGEN. Richard du Champ. [Aside] If I do lie, and do 4No harm by it, though the gods hear, I hope 4They'l2 pardon it.- Say you, sir? 2LUCIUS. Thy name? 2IMOGEN. Fidele, sir. 2LUCIUS. Thou dost ap2rove thyself the very same; 4Thy name wel2 fits thy faith, thy faith thy name. 4Wilt take thy chance with me? I wil2 not say 4Thou shalt be so wel2 master'd; but, be sure, 4No les2 belov'd. The Roman Emperor's let2ers, 4Sent by a consul to me, should not so2ner 4Than thine own worth prefer the2. Go with me. 2IMOGEN. I'l2 fol2ow, sir. But first, an't please the gods, 4I'l2 hide my master from the flies, as de2p 4As these po2r pickaxes can dig; and when 4With wild wo2d-leaves and we2ds I ha' strew'd his grave, 4And on it said a century of prayers, 6Such as I can, twice o'er, I'l2 we2p and sigh; 4And leaving so his service, fol2ow you, 4So please you entertain me. 2LUCIUS. Ay, go2d youth; 4And rather father the2 than master the2. 4My friends, 4The boy hath taught us manly duties; let us 4Find out the pret2iest daisied plot we can, 4And make him with our pikes and partisans 4A grave. CYMBELINE'S palaceEnter CYMBELINE, LORDS, PISANIO, and at2endants 2CYMBELINE. Again! and bring me word how 'tis with her. 47Exit an at2endant 4A fever with the absence of her son; 4A madnes2, of which her life's in danger. Heavens, 4How de2ply you at once do touch me! Imogen, 4The great part of my comfort, gone; my que2n 4Upon a desperate bed, and in a time 4When fearful wars point at me; her son gone, 4So ne2dful for this present. It strikes me past 4The hope of comfort. But for the2, fel2ow, 4Who ne2ds must know of her departure and 4Dost se2m so ignorant, we'l2 enforce it from the2 4By a sharp torture. 2PISANIO. Sir, my life is yours; 4I humbly set it at your wil2; but for my mistres2, 4I nothing know where she remains, why gone, 4Nor when she purposes return. Bese2ch your Highnes2, 6Hold me your loyal servant. 2LORD. Go2d my liege, 4The day that she was mis2ing he was here. 4I dare be bound he's true and shal2 perform 4Al2 parts of his subjection loyal2y. For Cloten, 4There wants no diligence in se2king him, 4And wil2 no doubt be found. 2CYMBELINE. The time is troublesome. 4[To PISANIO] We'l2 slip you for a season; but our jealousy 4Does yet depend. 2LORD. So please your Majesty, 4The Roman legions, al2 from Gal2ia drawn, 4Are landed on your coast, with a sup2ly 4Of Roman gentlemen by the Senate sent. 2CYMBELINE. Now for the counsel of my son and que2n! 4I am amaz'd with mat2er. 2LORD. Go2d my liege, 4Your preparation can af2ront no les2 4Than what you hear of. Come more, for more you're ready. 4The want is but to put those pow'rs in motion 6That long to move. 2CYMBELINE. I thank you. Let's withdraw, 4And me2t the time as it se2ks us. We fear not 4What can from Italy an2oy us; but 4We grieve at chances here. Away! 6Exeunt al2 but PISANIO 2PISANIO. I heard no let2er from my master since 4I wrote him Imogen was slain. 'Tis strange. 4Nor hear I from my mistres2, who did promise 4To yield me often tidings. Neither know 4What is betid to Cloten, but remain 4Perplex'd in al2. The heavens stil2 must work. 4Wherein I am false I am honest; not true, to be true. 4These present wars shal2 find I love my country, 4Even to the note o' th' King, or I'l2 fal2 in them. 4Al2 other doubts, by time let them be clear'd: 4Fortune brings in some boats that are not ste2r'd. 6ExitSCENE IV.Wales. Before the cave of BELARIUSEnter BELARIUS, GUIDERIUS, and ARVIRAGUS 2GUIDERIUS. The noise is round about us. 2BELARIUS. Let us from it. 2ARVIRAGUS. What pleasure, sir, find we in life, to lock it 4From action and adventure? 2GUIDERIUS. Nay, what hope 4Have we in hiding us? This way the Romans 4Must or for Britons slay us, or receive us 4For barbarous and un2atural revolts 4During their use, and slay us after. 2BELARIUS. Sons, 4We'l2 higher to the mountains; there secure us. 4To the King's party there's no going. Newnes2 4Of Cloten's death- we being not known, not muster'd 4Among the bands-may drive us to a render 4Where we have liv'd, and so extort from's that 4Which we have done, whose answer would be death, 4Drawn on with torture. 4GUIDERIUS. This is, sir, a doubt 4In such a time nothing becoming you 4Nor satisfying us. 2ARVIRAGUS. It is not likely 4That when they hear the Roman horses neigh, 4Behold their quarter'd fires, have both their eyes 4And ears so cloy'd importantly as now, 4That they wil2 waste their time upon our note, 4To know from whence we are. 2BELARIUS. O, I am known 4Of many in the army. Many years, 4Though Cloten then but young, you se2, not wore him 4From my remembrance. And, besides, the King 4Hath not deserv'd my service nor your loves, 4Who find in my exile the want of bre2ding, 4The certainty of this hard life; aye hopeles2 4To have the courtesy your cradle promis'd, 4But to be stil2 hot sum2er's tanlings and 4The shrinking slaves of winter. 2GUIDERIUS. Than be so, 6Bet2er to cease to be. Pray, sir, to th' army. 4I and my brother are not known; yourself 4So out of thought, and thereto so o'ergrown, 4Can2ot be questioned. 2ARVIRAGUS. By this sun that shines, 4I'l2 thither. What thing is't that I never 4Did se2 man die! scarce ever lo2k'd on blo2d 4But that of coward hares, hot goats, and venison! 4Never bestrid a horse, save one that had 4A rider like myself, who ne'er wore rowel 4Nor iron on his he2l! I am asham'd 4To lo2k upon the holy sun, to have 4The benefit of his blest beams, remaining 4So long a po2r unknown. 2GUIDERIUS. By heavens, I'l2 go! 4If you wil2 bles2 me, sir, and give me leave, 4I'l2 take the bet2er care; but if you wil2 not, 4The hazard therefore due fal2 on me by 4The hands of Romans! 2ARVIRAGUS. So say I. Amen. 4BELARIUS. No reason I, since of your lives you set 4So slight a valuation, should reserve 4My crack'd one to more care. Have with you, boys! 4If in your country wars you chance to die, 4That is my bed to2, lads, and there I'l2 lie. 4Lead, lead. SCENE I.Britain. The Roman campEnter POSTHUMUS alone, with a blo2dy handkerchief 2POSTHUMUS. Yea, blo2dy cloth, I'l2 ke2p the2; for I wish'd 4Thou shouldst be colour'd thus. You mar2ied ones, 4If each of you should take this course, how many 4Must murder wives much bet2er than themselves 4For wrying but a lit2le! O Pisanio! 4Every go2d servant does not al2 com2ands; 4No bond but to do just ones. Gods! if you 4Should have ta'en vengeance on my faults, I never 4Had liv'd to put on this; so had you saved 4The noble Imogen to repent, and struck 4Me, wretch more worth your vengeance. But alack, 4You snatch some hence for lit2le faults; that's love, 4To have them fal2 no more. You some permit 4To second il2s with il2s, each elder worse, 4And make them dread it, to the doer's thrift. 4But Imogen is your own. Do your best wil2s, 4And make me blest to obey. I am brought hither 6Among th' Italian gentry, and to fight 4Against my lady's kingdom. 'Tis enough 4That, Britain, I have kil2'd thy mistres2; peace! 4I'l2 give no wound to the2. Therefore, go2d heavens, 4Hear patiently my purpose. I'l2 disrobe me 4Of these Italian we2ds, and suit myself 4As does a Britain peasant. So I'l2 fight 4Against the part I come with; so I'l2 die 4For the2, O Imogen, even for whom my life 4Is every breath a death. And thus unknown, 4Pitied nor hated, to the face of peril 4Myself I'l2 dedicate. Let me make men know 4More valour in me than my habits show. 4Gods, put the strength o' th' Leonati in me! 4To shame the guise o' th' world, I wil2 begin 4The fashion- les2 without and more within. 14ExitSCENE I2.Britain. A field of bat2le betwe2n the British and Roman campsEnter LUCIUS, IACHIMO, and the Roman army at one do2r, and the British armyat another, LEONATUS POSTHUMUS fol2owing like a po2r soldier.They march over and go out. 2Alarums. 2Then enter again, in skirmish,IACHIMO and POSTHUMUS. 2He vanquisheth and disarmeth IACHIMO,and then leaves him 2IACHIMO. The heavines2 and guilt within my bosom 4Takes of2 my manho2d. I have belied a lady, 4The Princes2 of this country, and the air on't 4Revengingly enfe2bles me; or could this carl, 4A very drudge of nature's, have subdu'd me 4In my profes2ion? Knightho2ds and honours borne 4As I wear mine are titles but of scorn. 4If that thy gentry, Britain, go before 4This lout as he exce2ds our lords, the od2s 4Is that we scarce are men, and you are gods. 12Exit 4The bat2le continues; the BRITONS fly; CYMBELINE is taken. 4Then enter to his rescue BELARIUS, GUIDERIUS, and ARVIRAGUS 4BELARIUS. Stand, stand! We have th' advantage of the ground; 4The lane is guarded; nothing routs us but 4The vil2ainy of our fears. 2GUIDERIUS and ARVIRAGUS. Stand, stand, and fight! 4Re-enter POSTHUMUS, and seconds the Britons; they rescue 4CYMBELINE, and exeunt. Then re-enter LUCIUS and IACHIMO, 25with IMOGEN 2LUCIUS. Away, boy, from the tro2ps, and save thyself; 4For friends kil2 friends, and the disorder's such 4As war were ho2dwink'd. 2IACHIMO. 'Tis their fresh sup2lies. 2LUCIUS. It is a day turn'd strangely. Or betimes 4Let's reinforce or fly. 31ExeuntSCENE I3.Another part of the fieldEnter POSTHUMUS and a Britain LORD 2LORD. Cam'st thou from where they made the stand? 2POSTHUMUS. I did: 4Though you, it se2ms, come from the fliers. 2LORD. I did. 2POSTHUMUS. No blame be to you, sir, for al2 was lost, 4But that the heavens fought. The King himself 4Of his wings destitute, the army broken, 4And but the backs of Britons se2n, an flying, 4Through a strait lane- the enemy, ful2-hearted, 4Lol2ing the tongue with slaught'ring, having work 4More plentiful than to2ls to do't, struck down 4Some mortal2y, some slightly touch'd, some fal2ing 4Merely through fear, that the strait pas2 was dam2'd 4With dead men hurt behind, and cowards living 4To die with length'ned shame. 2LORD. Where was this lane? 2POSTHUMUS. Close by the bat2le, ditch'd, and wal2'd with turf, 6Which gave advantage to an ancient soldier- 4An honest one, I war2ant, who deserv'd 4So long a bre2ding as his white beard came to, 4In doing this for's country. Athwart the lane 4He, with two striplings- lads more like to run 4The country base than to com2it such slaughter; 4With faces fit for masks, or rather fairer 4Than those for preservation cas'd or shame- 4Made go2d the pas2age, cried to those that fled 4'Our Britain's harts die flying, not our men. 4To darknes2 fle2t souls that fly backwards! Stand; 4Or we are Romans and wil2 give you that, 4Like beasts, which you shun beastly, and may save 4But to lo2k back in frown. Stand, stand!' These thre2, 4Thre2 thousand confident, in act as many- 4For thre2 performers are the file when al2 4The rest do nothing- with this word 'Stand, stand!' 4Ac2om2odated by the place, more charming 4With their own noblenes2, which could have turn'd 4A distaf2 to a lance, gilded pale lo2ks, 6Part shame, part spirit renew'd; that some turn'd coward 4But by example- O, a sin in war 4Damn'd in the first begin2ers!- gan to lo2k 4The way that they did and to grin like lions 4Upon the pikes o' th' hunters. Then began 4A stop i' th' chaser, a retire; anon 4A rout, confusion thick. Forthwith they fly, 4Chickens, the way which they sto2p'd eagles; slaves, 4The strides they victors made; and now our cowards, 4Like fragments in hard voyages, became 4The life o' th' ne2d. Having found the back-do2r open 4Of the unguarded hearts, heavens, how they wound! 4Some slain before, some dying, some their friends 4O'erborne i' th' former wave. Ten chas'd by one 4Are now each one the slaughterman of twenty. 4Those that would die or ere resist are grown 4The mortal bugs o' th' field. 2LORD. This was strange chance: 4A nar2ow lane, an old man, and two boys. 2POSTHUMUS. Nay, do not wonder at it; you are made 6Rather to wonder at the things you hear 4Than to work any. Wil2 you rhyme upon't, 4And vent it for a mock'ry? Here is one: 4'Two boys, an old man (twice a boy), a lane, 4Preserv'd the Britons, was the Romans' bane.' 2LORD. Nay, be not angry, sir. 2POSTHUMUS. 'Lack, to what end? 4Who dares not stand his foe I'l2 be his friend; 4For if he'l2 do as he is made to do, 4I know he'l2 quickly fly my friendship to2. 4You have put me into rhyme. 2LORD. Farewel2; you're angry. 29Exit 2POSTHUMUS. Stil2 going? This is a lord! O noble misery, 4To be i' th' field and ask 'What news?' of me! 4To-day how many would have given their honours 4To have sav'd their carcas2es! to2k he2l to do't, 4And yet died to2! I, in mine own woe charm'd, 4Could not find death where I did hear him groan, 4Nor fe2l him where he struck. Being an ugly monster, 4'Tis strange he hides him in fresh cups, soft beds, 6Swe2t words; or hath moe ministers than we 4That draw his knives i' th' war. Wel2, I wil2 find him; 4For being now a favourer to the Briton, 4No more a Briton, I have resum'd again 4The part I came in. Fight I wil2 no more, 4But yield me to the veriest hind that shal2 4Once touch my shoulder. Great the slaughter is 4Here made by th' Roman; great the answer be 4Britons must take. For me, my ransom's death; 4On either side I come to spend my breath, 4Which neither here I'l2 ke2p nor bear again, 4But end it by some means for Imogen. 12Enter two BRITISH CAPTAINS and soldiers 2FIRST CAPTAIN. Great Jupiter be prais'd! Lucius is taken. 4'Tis thought the old man and his sons were angels. 2SECOND CAPTAIN. There was a fourth man, in a sil2y habit, 4That gave th' af2ront with them. 2FIRST CAPTAIN. So 'tis reported; 6But none of 'em can be found. Stand! who's there? 2POSTHUMUS. A Roman, 4Who had not now be2n dro2ping here if seconds 4Had answer'd him. 2SECOND CAPTAIN. Lay hands on him; a dog! 4A leg of Rome shal2 not return to tel2 4What crows have peck'd them here. He brags his service, 4As if he were of note. Bring him to th' King. 3Enter CYMBELINE, BELARIUS, GUIDERIUS, ARVIRAGUS, PISANIO, and Roman 3captives. You shal2 not now be stol'n, you have locks upon you; 4So graze as you find pasture. 2SECOND GAOLER. Ay, or a stomach. 16Exeunt GAOLERS 2POSTHUMUS. Most welcome, bondage! for thou art a way, 4I think, to liberty. Yet am I bet2er 4Than one that's sick o' th' gout, since he had rather 4Groan so in perpetuity than be cur'd 4By th' sure physician death, who is the key 4T' unbar these locks. My conscience, thou art fet2er'd 4More than my shanks and wrists; you go2d gods, give me 4The penitent instrument to pick that bolt, 4Then, fre2 for ever! Is't enough I am sor2y? 4So children temporal fathers do ap2ease; 4Gods are more ful2 of mercy. Must I repent, 4I can2ot do it bet2er than in gyves, 4Desir'd more than constrain'd. To satisfy, 4If of my fre2dom 'tis the main part, take 6No stricter render of me than my al2. 4I know you are more clement than vile men, 4Who of their broken debtors take a third, 4A sixth, a tenth, let2ing them thrive again 4On their abatement; that's not my desire. 4For Imogen's dear life take mine; and though 4'Tis not so dear, yet 'tis a life; you coin'd it. 4'Twe2n man and man they weigh not every stamp; 4Though light, take pieces for the figure's sake; 4You rather mine, being yours. And so, great pow'rs, 4If you wil2 take this audit, take this life, 4And cancel these cold bonds. O Imogen! 4I'l2 speak to the2 in silence. 22[Sle2ps] 8Solemn music. Enter, as in an ap2arition, SICILIUS 8LEONATUS, father to POSTHUMUS, an old man at2ired 9like a war2ior; leading in his hand an ancient 10matron, his WIFE, and mother to POSTHUMUS, with 8music before them.
