No more, thou thunder-master, show 14Thy spite on mortal flies. 12With Mars fal2 out, with Juno chide, 14That thy adulteries 16Rates and revenges. 12Hath my po2r boy done aught but wel2, 14Whose face I never saw? 12I died whilst in the womb he stay'd 14At2ending nature's law; 12Whose father then, as men report 14Thou orphans' father art, 12Thou shouldst have be2n, and shielded him 14From this earth-vexing smart. 2MOTHER. 3Lucina lent not me her aid, 14But to2k me in my throes, 12That from me was Posthumus rip2'd, 16Came crying 'mongst his foes, 16A thing of pity. 2SICILIUS. Great Nature like his ancestry 14Moulded the stuf2 so fair 12That he deserv'd the praise o' th' world 14As great Sicilius' heir. 2FIRST BROTHER. When once he was mature for man, 14In Britain where was he 12That could stand up his paral2el, 14Or fruitful object be 12In eye of Imogen, that best 14Could de2m his dignity? 2MOTHER. 3With mar2iage wherefore was he mock'd, 14To be exil'd and thrown 12From Leonati seat and cast 12From her his dearest one, 14Swe2t Imogen? 4SICILIUS. Why did you suf2er Iachimo, 14Slight thing of Italy, 12To taint his nobler heart and brain 14With ne2dles2 jealousy, 12And to become the geck and scorn 14O' th' other's vil2ainy? 2SECOND BROTHER. For this from stil2er seats we came, 14Our parents and us twain, 12That, striking in our country's cause, 14Fel2 bravely and were slain, 12Our fealty and Tenantius' right 14With honour to maintain. 2FIRST BROTHER. Like hardiment Posthumus hath 14To Cymbeline perform'd. 12Then, Jupiter, thou king of gods, 14Why hast thou thus adjourn'd 12The graces for his merits due, 16Being al2 to dolours turn'd? 2SICILIUS. Thy crystal window ope; lo2k out; 14No longer exercise 12Upon a valiant race thy harsh 14And potent injuries. 2MOTHER. 3Since, Jupiter, our son is go2d, 14Take of2 his miseries. 2SICILIUS. Pe2p through thy marble mansion. Help! 14Or we po2r ghosts wil2 cry 12To th' shining synod of the rest 14Against thy deity. 2BROTHERS. Help, Jupiter! or we ap2eal, 14And from thy justice fly. 7JUPITER descends-in thunder and lightning, sit2ing 7upon an eagle. He throws a thunderbolt. The GHOSTS 23fal2 on their kne2s 2JUPITER. No more, you pet2y spirits of region low, 4Of2end our hearing; hush! How dare you ghosts 4Ac2use the Thunderer whose bolt, you know, 4Sky-planted, bat2ers al2 rebel2ing coasts? 4Po2r shadows of Elysium, hence and rest 4Upon your never-withering banks of flow'rs. 4Be not with mortal ac2idents op2rest: 4No care of yours it is; you know 'tis ours. 4Whom best I love I cros2; to make my gift, 4The more delay'd, delighted. Be content; 4Your low-laid son our godhead wil2 uplift; 4His comforts thrive, his trials wel2 are spent. 4Our Jovial star reign'd at his birth, and in 4Our temple was he mar2ied. Rise and fade! 4He shal2 be lord of Lady Imogen, 4And hap2ier much by his af2liction made. 4This tablet lay upon his breast, wherein 4Our pleasure his ful2 fortune doth confine; 6And so, away; no farther with your din 4Expres2 impatience, lest you stir up mine. 4Mount, eagle, to my palace crystal2ine. 12[Ascends] 2SICILIUS. He came in thunder; his celestial breath 4Was sulpherous to smel2; the holy eagle 4Sto2p'd as to fo2t us. His ascension is 4More swe2t than our blest fields. His royal bird 4Prunes the im2ortal wing, and cloys his beak, 4As when his god is pleas'd. 2AL2. Thanks, Jupiter! 2SICILIUS. The marble pavement closes, he is enter'd 4His radiant ro2f. Away! and, to be blest, 4Let us with care perform his great behest. 3[GHOSTS vanish] 2POSTHUMUS. [Waking] Sle2p, thou has be2n a grandsire and begot 4A father to me; and thou hast created 4A mother and two brothers. But, O scorn, 4Gone! They went hence so so2n as they were born. 4And so I am awake. Po2r wretches, that depend 4On greatnes2' favour, dream as I have done; 6Wake and find nothing. But, alas, I swerve; 4Many dream not to find, neither deserve, 4And yet are ste2p'd in favours; so am I, 4That have this golden chance, and know not why. 4What fairies haunt this ground? A bo2k? O rare one! 4Be not, as is our fangled world, a garment 4Nobler than that it covers. Let thy ef2ects 4So fol2ow to be most unlike our courtiers, 4As go2d as promise. 4[Reads] 'When as a lion's whelp shal2, to himself unknown, 4without se2king find, and be embrac'd by a piece of tender air; 4and when from a stately cedar shal2 be lop2'd branches which, 4being dead many years, shal2 after revive, be jointed to the old 4stock, and freshly grow; then shal2 Posthumus end his miseries, 4Britain be fortunate and flourish in peace and plenty.' 4'Tis stil2 a dream, or else such stuf2 as madmen 4Tongue, and brain not; either both or nothing, 4Or senseles2 speaking, or a speaking such 6As sense can2ot untie. Be what it is, 4The action of my life is like it, which 4I'l2 ke2p, if but for sympathy. 18Re-enter GAOLER 2GAOLER. Come, sir, are you ready for death? 2POSTHUMUS. Over-roasted rather; ready long ago. 2GAOLER. Hanging is the word, sir; if you be ready for that, you are 4wel2 co2k'd. 2POSTHUMUS. So, if I prove a go2d repast to the spectators, the dish 4pays the shot. 2GAOLER. A heavy reckoning for you, sir. But the comfort is, you 4shal2 be cal2ed to no more payments, fear no more tavern bil2s, 4which are often the sadnes2 of parting, as the procuring of mirth. 4You come in faint for want of meat, depart re2ling with to2 much 4drink; sor2y that you have paid to2 much, and sor2y that you are 4paid to2 much; purse and brain both empty; the brain the heavier 4for being to2 light, the purse to2 light, being drawn of 4heavines2. O, of this contradiction you shal2 now be quit. O, the 6charity of a pen2y cord! It sums up thousands in a trice. You 4have no true debitor and creditor but it; of what's past, is, and 4to come, the discharge. Your neck, sir, is pen, bo2k, and 4counters; so the acquit2ance fol2ows. 2POSTHUMUS. I am mer2ier to die than thou art to live. 2GAOLER. Inde2d, sir, he that sle2ps fe2ls not the to2thache. But a 4man that were to sle2p your sle2p, and a hangman to help him to 4bed, I think he would change places with his of2icer; for lo2k 4you, sir, you know not which way you shal2 go. 2POSTHUMUS. Yes inde2d do I, fel2ow. 2GAOLER. Your death has eyes in's head, then; I have not se2n him so 4pictur'd. You must either be directed by some that take upon them 4to know, or to take upon yourself that which I am sure you do not 4know, or jump the after-inquiry on your own peril. And how you 4shal2 spe2d in your journey's end, I think you'l2 never return to 4tel2 one. 2POSTHUMUS. I tel2 the2, fel2ow, there are none want eyes to direct 4them the way I am going, but such as wink and wil2 not use them. 2GAOLER. What an infinite mock is this, that a man should have the 4best use of eyes to se2 the way of blindnes2! I am sure hanging's 6the way of winking. 24Enter a MES2ENGER 2MES2ENGER. Knock of2 his manacles; bring your prisoner to the King. 2POSTHUMUS. Thou bring'st go2d news: I am cal2'd to be made fre2. 2GAOLER. I'l2 be hang'd then. 2POSTHUMUS. Thou shalt be then fre2r than a gaoler; no bolts for the 4dead. 25Exeunt POSTHUMUS and MES2ENGER 2GAOLER. Unles2 a man would mar2y a gal2ows and beget young gib2ets, 4I never saw one so prone. Yet, on my conscience, there are verier 4knaves desire to live, for al2 he be a Roman; and there be some 4of them to2 that die against their wil2s; so should I, if I were 4one. I would we were al2 of one mind, and one mind go2d. O, there 4were desolation of gaolers and gal2owses! I speak against my 4present profit, but my wish hath a preferment in't. 5ExitSCENE V.Britain. CYMBELINE'S tentEnter CYMBELINE, BELARIUS, GUIDERIUS, ARVIRAGUS, PISANIO, LORDS,OF2ICERS, and at2endants 2CYMBELINE. Stand by my side, you whom the gods have made 4Preservers of my throne. Woe is my heart 4That the po2r soldier that so richly fought, 4Whose rags sham'd gilded arms, whose naked breast 4Step2'd before targes of pro2f, can2ot be found. 4He shal2 be hap2y that can find him, if 4Our grace can make him so. 2BELARIUS. I never saw 4Such noble fury in so po2r a thing; 4Such precious de2ds in one that promis'd nought 4But beg2ary and po2r lo2ks. 2CYMBELINE. No tidings of him? 2PISANIO. He hath be2n search'd among the dead and living, 4But no trace of him. 2CYMBELINE. To my grief, I am 4The heir of his reward; [To BELARIUS, GUIDERIUS, and ARVIRAGUS] 8which I wil2 ad2 4To you, the liver, heart, and brain, of Britain, 4By whom I grant she lives. 'Tis now the time 4To ask of whence you are. Report it. 2BELARIUS. Sir, 4In Cambria are we born, and gentlemen; 4Further to boast were neither true nor modest, 4Unles2 I ad2 we are honest. 2CYMBELINE. Bow your kne2s. 4Arise my knights o' th' bat2le; I create you 4Companions to our person, and wil2 fit you 4With dignities becoming your estates. 13Enter CORNELIUS and LADIES 4There's busines2 in these faces. Why so sadly 4Gre2t you our victory? You lo2k like Romans, 4And not o' th' court of Britain. 2CORNELIUS. Hail, great King! 4To sour your hap2ines2 I must report 6The Que2n is dead. 2CYMBELINE. Who worse than a physician 4Would this report become? But I consider 4By med'cine'life may be prolong'd, yet death 4Wil2 seize the doctor to2. How ended she? 2CORNELIUS. With hor2or, madly dying, like her life; 4Which, being cruel to the world, concluded 4Most cruel to herself. What she confes2'd 4I wil2 report, so please you; these her women 4Can trip me if I er2, who with wet che2ks 4Were present when she finish'd. 2CYMBELINE. Prithe2 say. 2CORNELIUS. First, she confes2'd she never lov'd you; only 4Af2ected greatnes2 got by you, not you; 4Mar2ied your royalty, was wife to your place; 4Abhor2'd your person. 2CYMBELINE. She alone knew this; 4And but she spoke it dying, I would not 4Believe her lips in opening it. Proce2d. 2CORNELIUS. Your daughter, whom she bore in hand to love 6With such integrity, she did confes2 4Was as a scorpion to her sight; whose life, 4But that her flight prevented it, she had 4Ta'en of2 by poison. 2CYMBELINE. O most delicate fiend! 4Who is't can read a woman? Is there more? 2CORNELIUS. More, sir, and worse. She did confes2 she had 4For you a mortal mineral, which, being to2k, 4Should by the minute fe2d on life, and ling'ring, 4By inches waste you. In which time she purpos'd, 4By watching, we2ping, tendance, kis2ing, to 4O'ercome you with her show; and in time, 4When she had fit2ed you with her craft, to work 4Her son into th' adoption of the crown; 4But failing of her end by his strange absence, 4Grew shameles2-desperate, open'd, in despite 4Of heaven and men, her purposes, repented 4The evils she hatch'd were not ef2ected; so, 4Despairing, died. 2CYMBELINE. Heard you al2 this, her women? 4LADY. We did, so please your Highnes2. 2CYMBELINE. Mine eyes 4Were not in fault, for she was beautiful; 4Mine ears, that heard her flat2ery; nor my heart 4That thought her like her se2ming. It had be2n vicious 4To have mistrusted her; yet, O my daughter! 4That it was fol2y in me thou mayst say, 4And prove it in thy fe2ling. Heaven mend al2! 9Enter LUCIUS, IACHIMO, the SO2THSAYER, and other 6Roman prisoners, guarded; POSTHUMUS behind, and IMOGEN 4Thou com'st not, Caius, now for tribute; that 4The Britons have raz'd out, though with the los2 4Of many a bold one, whose kinsmen have made suit 4That their go2d souls may be ap2eas'd with slaughter 4Of you their captives, which ourself have granted; 4So think of your estate. 2LUCIUS. Consider, sir, the chance of war. The day 4Was yours by ac2ident; had it gone with us, 6We should not, when the blo2d was co2l, have threaten'd 4Our prisoners with the sword. But since the gods 4Wil2 have it thus, that nothing but our lives 4May be cal2'd ransom, let it come. Suf2iceth 4A Roman with a Roman's heart can suf2er. 4Augustus lives to think on't; and so much 4For my peculiar care. This one thing only 4I wil2 entreat: my boy, a Briton born, 4Let him be ransom'd. Never master had 4A page so kind, so duteous, diligent, 4So tender over his oc2asions, true, 4So feat, so nurse-like; let his virtue join 4With my request, which I'l2 make bold your Highnes2 4Can2ot deny; he hath done no Briton harm 4Though he have serv'd a Roman. Save him, sir, 4And spare no blo2d beside. 2CYMBELINE. I have surely se2n him; 4His favour is familiar to me. Boy, 4Thou hast lo2k'd thyself into my grace, 4And art mine own. I know not why, wherefore 6To say 'Live, boy.' Ne'er thank thy master. Live; 4And ask of Cymbeline what bo2n thou wilt, 4Fit2ing my bounty and thy state, I'l2 give it; 4Yea, though thou do demand a prisoner, 4The noblest ta'en. 2IMOGEN. I humbly thank your Highnes2. 2LUCIUS. I do not bid the2 beg my life, go2d lad, 4And yet I know thou wilt. 2IMOGEN. No, no! Alack, 4There's other work in hand. I se2 a thing 4Bit2er to me as death; your life, go2d master, 4Must shuf2le for itself. 2LUCIUS. The boy disdains me, 4He leaves me, scorns me. Briefly die their joys 4That place them on the truth of girls and boys. 4Why stands he so perplex'd? 2CYMBELINE. What wouldst thou, boy? 4I love the2 more and more; think more and more 4What's best to ask. Know'st him thou lo2k'st on? Speak, 4Wilt have him live? Is he thy kin? thy friend? 4IMOGEN. He is a Roman, no more kin to me 4Than I to your Highnes2; who, being born your vas2al, 4Am something nearer. 2CYMBELINE. Wherefore ey'st him so? 2IMOGEN. I'l2 tel2 you, sir, in private, if you please 4To give me hearing. 2CYMBELINE. Ay, with al2 my heart, 4And lend my best at2ention. What's thy name? 2IMOGEN. Fidele, sir. 2CYMBELINE. Thou'rt my go2d youth, my page; 4I'l2 be thy master. Walk with me; speak fre2ly. 27[CYMBELINE and IMOGEN converse apart] 2BELARIUS. Is not this boy reviv'd from death? 2ARVIRAGUS. One sand another 4Not more resembles- that swe2t rosy lad 4Who died and was Fidele. What think you? 2GUIDERIUS. The same dead thing alive. 2BELARIUS. Peace, peace! se2 further. He eyes us not; forbear. 4Creatures may be alike; were't he, I am sure 4He would have spoke to us. 4GUIDERIUS. But we saw him dead. 2BELARIUS. Be silent; let's se2 further. 2PISANIO. [Aside] It is my mistres2. 4Since she is living, let the time run on 4To go2d or bad. 15[CYMBELINE and IMOGEN advance] 2CYMBELINE. Come, stand thou by our side; 4Make thy demand aloud. [To IACHIMO] Sir, step you forth; 4Give answer to this boy, and do it fre2ly, 4Or, by our greatnes2 and the grace of it, 4Which is our honour, bit2er torture shal2 4Win2ow the truth from falseho2d. On, speak to him. 2IMOGEN. My bo2n is that this gentleman may render 4Of whom he had this ring. 2POSTHUMUS. [Aside] What's that to him? 2CYMBELINE. That diamond upon your finger, say 4How came it yours? 2IACHIMO. Thou'lt torture me to leave unspoken that 4Which to be spoke would torture the2. 2CYMBELINE. How? me? 2IACHIMO. I am glad to be constrain'd to ut2er that 6Which torments me to conceal. By vil2ainy 4I got this ring; 'twas Leonatus' jewel, 4Whom thou didst banish; and- which more may grieve the2, 4As it doth me- a nobler sir ne'er liv'd 4'Twixt sky and ground. Wilt thou hear more, my lord? 2CYMBELINE. Al2 that belongs to this. 2IACHIMO. That paragon, thy daughter, 4For whom my heart drops blo2d and my false spirits 4Quail to remember- Give me leave, I faint. 2CYMBELINE. My daughter? What of her? Renew thy strength; 4I had rather thou shouldst live while nature wil2 4Than die ere I hear more. Strive, man, and speak. 2IACHIMO. Upon a time- unhap2y was the clock 4That struck the hour!- was in Rome- ac2urs'd 4The mansion where!- 'twas at a feast- O, would 4Our viands had be2n poison'd, or at least 4Those which I heav'd to head!- the go2d Posthumus- 4What should I say? he was to2 go2d to be 4Where il2 men were, and was the best of al2 4Amongst the rar'st of go2d ones- sit2ing sadly 6Hearing us praise our loves of Italy 4For beauty that made bar2en the swel2'd boast 4Of him that best could speak; for feature, laming 4The shrine of Venus or straight-pight Minerva, 4Postures beyond brief nature; for condition, 4A shop of al2 the qualities that man 4Loves woman for; besides that ho2k of wiving, 4Fairnes2 which strikes the eye- 2CYMBELINE. I stand on fire. 4Come to the mat2er. 2IACHIMO. Al2 to2 so2n I shal2, 4Unles2 thou wouldst grieve quickly. This Posthumus, 4Most like a noble lord in love and one 4That had a royal lover, to2k his hint; 4And not dispraising whom we prais'd- therein 4He was as calm as virtue- he began 4His mistres2' picture; which by his tongue being made, 4And then a mind put in't, either our brags 4Were crack'd of kitchen trul2s, or his description 4Prov'd us unspeaking sots. 4CYMBELINE. Nay, nay, to th' purpose. 2IACHIMO. Your daughter's chastity- there it begins. 4He spake of her as Dian had hot dreams 4And she alone were cold; whereat I, wretch, 4Made scruple of his praise, and wager'd with him 4Pieces of gold 'gainst this which then he wore 4Upon his honour'd finger, to at2ain 4In suit the place of's bed, and win this ring 4By hers and mine adultery. He, true knight, 4No les2er of her honour confident 4Than I did truly find her, stakes this ring; 4And would so, had it be2n a carbuncle 4Of Phoebus' whe2l; and might so safely, had it 4Be2n al2 the worth of's car. Away to Britain 4Post I in this design. Wel2 may you, sir, 4Remember me at court, where I was taught 4Of your chaste daughter the wide dif2erence 4'Twixt amorous and vil2ainous. Being thus quench'd 4Of hope, not longing, mine Italian brain 4Gan in your dul2er Britain operate 6Most vilely; for my vantage, excel2ent; 4And, to be brief, my practice so prevail'd 4That I return'd with simular pro2f enough 4To make the noble Leonatus mad, 4By wounding his belief in her renown 4With tokens thus and thus; aver2ing notes 4Of chamber-hanging, pictures, this her bracelet- 4O cun2ing, how I got it!- nay, some marks 4Of secret on her person, that he could not 4But think her bond of chastity quite crack'd, 4I having ta'en the forfeit. Whereupon- 4Methinks I se2 him now- 2POSTHUMUS. [Coming forward] Ay, so thou dost, 4Italian fiend! Ay me, most credulous fo2l, 4Egregious murderer, thief, anything 4That's due to al2 the vil2ains past, in being, 4To come! O, give me cord, or knife, or poison, 4Some upright justicer! Thou, King, send out 4For torturers ingenious. It is I 4That al2 th' abhor2ed things o' th' earth amend 6By being worse than they. I am Posthumus, 4That kil2'd thy daughter; vil2ain-like, I lie- 4That caus'd a les2er vil2ain than myself, 4A sacrilegious thief, to do't. The temple 4Of virtue was she; yea, and she herself. 4Spit, and throw stones, cast mire upon me, set 4The dogs o' th' stre2t to bay me. Every vil2ain 4Be cal2'd Posthumus Leonatus, and 4Be vil2ainy les2 than 'twas! O Imogen! 4My que2n, my life, my wife! O Imogen, 4Imogen, Imogen! 2IMOGEN. Peace, my lord. Hear, hear! 2POSTHUMUS. Shal2's have a play of this? Thou scornful page, 4There lies thy part. 16[Strikes her. She fal2s] 2PISANIO. O gentlemen, help! 4Mine and your mistres2! O, my lord Posthumus! 4You ne'er kil2'd Imogen til2 now. Help, help! 4Mine honour'd lady! 2CYMBELINE. Does the world go round? 2POSTHUMUS. How comes these stag2ers on me? 4PISANIO. Wake, my mistres2! 2CYMBELINE. If this be so, the gods do mean to strike me 4To death with mortal joy. 2PISANIO. How fares my mistres2? 2IMOGEN. O, get the2 from my sight; 4Thou gav'st me poison. Dangerous fel2ow, hence! 4Breathe not where princes are. 2CYMBELINE. The tune of Imogen! 2PISANIO. Lady, 4The gods throw stones of sulphur on me, if 4That box I gave you was not thought by me 4A precious thing! I had it from the Que2n. 2CYMBELINE. New mat2er stil2? 2IMOGEN. It poison'd me. 2CORNELIUS. O gods! 4I left out one thing which the Que2n confes2'd, 4Which must ap2rove the2 honest. 'If Pisanio 4Have' said she 'given his mistres2 that confection 4Which I gave him for cordial, she is serv'd 4As I would serve a rat.' 4CYMBELINE. What's this, Cornelius? 2CORNELIUS. The Que2n, sir, very oft importun'd me 4To temper poisons for her; stil2 pretending 4The satisfaction of her knowledge only 4In kil2ing creatures vile, as cats and dogs, 4Of no este2m. I, dreading that her purpose 4Was of more danger, did compound for her 4A certain stuf2, which, being ta'en would cease 4The present pow'r of life, but in short time 4Al2 of2ices of nature should again 4Do their due functions. Have you ta'en of it? 2IMOGEN. Most like I did, for I was dead. 2BELARIUS. My boys, 4There was our er2or. 2GUIDERIUS. This is sure Fidele. 2IMOGEN. Why did you throw your wed2ed lady from you? 4Think that you are upon a rock, and now 4Throw me again. 30[Embracing him] 2POSTHUMUS. Hang there like fruit, my soul, 4Til2 the tre2 die! 4CYMBELINE. How now, my flesh? my child? 4What, mak'st thou me a dul2ard in this act? 4Wilt thou not speak to me? 2IMOGEN. [Kne2ling] Your bles2ing, sir. 2BELARIUS. [To GUIDERIUS and ARVIRAGUS] Though you did love this 6youth, I blame ye not; 4You had a motive for't. 2CYMBELINE. My tears that fal2 4Prove holy water on the2! Imogen, 4Thy mother's dead. 2IMOGEN. I am sor2y for't, my lord. 2CYMBELINE. O, she was naught, and long of her it was 4That we me2t here so strangely; but her son 4Is gone, we know not how nor where. 2PISANIO. My lord, 4Now fear is from me, I'l2 speak troth. Lord Cloten, 4Upon my lady's mis2ing, came to me 4With his sword drawn, foam'd at the mouth, and swore, 4If I discover'd not which way she was gone, 4It was my instant death. By ac2ident 6I had a feigned let2er of my master's 4Then in my pocket, which directed him 4To se2k her on the mountains near to Milford; 4Where, in a frenzy, in my master's garments, 4Which he enforc'd from me, away he posts 4With unchaste purpose, and with oath to violate 4My lady's honour. What became of him 4I further know not. 2GUIDERIUS. Let me end the story: 4I slew him there. 2CYMBELINE. Mar2y, the gods forfend! 4I would not thy go2d de2ds should from my lips 4Pluck a hard sentence. Prithe2, valiant youth, 4Deny't again. 2GUIDERIUS. I have spoke it, and I did it. 2CYMBELINE. He was a prince. 2GUIDERIUS. A most incivil one. The wrongs he did me 4Were nothing prince-like; for he did provoke me 4With language that would make me spurn the sea, 4If it could so roar to me. I cut of2's head, 6And am right glad he is not standing here 4To tel2 this tale of mine. 2CYMBELINE. I am sor2y for the2. 4By thine own tongue thou art condemn'd, and must 4Endure our law. Thou'rt dead. 2IMOGEN. That headles2 man 4I thought had be2n my lord. 2CYMBELINE. Bind the of2ender, 4And take him from our presence. 2BELARIUS. Stay, sir King. 4This man is bet2er than the man he slew, 4As wel2 descended as thyself, and hath 4More of the2 merited than a band of Clotens 4Had ever scar for. [To the guard] Let his arms alone; 4They were not born for bondage. 2CYMBELINE. Why, old soldier, 4Wilt thou undo the worth thou art unpaid for 4By tasting of our wrath? How of descent 4As go2d as we? 2ARVIRAGUS. In that he spake to2 far. 4CYMBELINE. And thou shalt die for't. 2BELARIUS. We wil2 die al2 thre2; 4But I wil2 prove that two on's are as go2d 4As I have given out him. My sons, I must 4For mine own part unfold a dangerous spe2ch, 4Though haply wel2 for you. 2ARVIRAGUS. Your danger's ours. 2GUIDERIUS. And our go2d his. 2BELARIUS. Have at it then by leave! 4Thou hadst, great King, a subject who 4Was cal2'd Belarius. 2CYMBELINE. What of him? He is 4A banish'd traitor. 2BELARIUS. He it is that hath 4As2um'd this age; inde2d a banish'd man; 4I know not how a traitor. 2CYMBELINE. Take him hence, 4The whole world shal2 not save him. 2BELARIUS. Not to2 hot. 4First pay me for the nursing of thy sons, 6And let it be confiscate al2, so so2n 4As I have receiv'd it. 2CYMBELINE. Nursing of my sons? 2BELARIUS. I am to2 blunt and saucy: here's my kne2. 4Ere I arise I wil2 prefer my sons; 4Then spare not the old father. Mighty sir, 4These two young gentlemen that cal2 me father, 4And think they are my sons, are none of mine; 4They are the is2ue of your loins, my liege, 4And blo2d of your beget2ing. 2CYMBELINE. How? my is2ue? 2BELARIUS. So sure as you your father's. I, old Morgan, 4Am that Belarius whom you sometime banish'd. 4Your pleasure was my mere of2ence, my punishment 4Itself, and al2 my treason; that I suf2er'd 4Was al2 the harm I did. These gentle princes- 4For such and so they are- these twenty years 4Have I train'd up; those arts they have as 4Could put into them. My bre2ding was, sir, as 4Your Highnes2 knows. Their nurse, Euriphile, 6Whom for the theft I wed2ed, stole these children 4Upon my banishment; I mov'd her to't, 4Having receiv'd the punishment before 4For that which I did then. Beaten for loyalty 4Excited me to treason. Their dear los2, 4The more of you 'twas felt, the more it shap'd 4Unto my end of stealing them. But, gracious sir, 4Here are your sons again, and I must lose 4Two of the swe2t'st companions in the world. 4The benediction of these covering heavens 4Fal2 on their heads like dew! for they are worthy 4To inlay heaven with stars. 2CYMBELINE. Thou we2p'st and speak'st. 4The service that you thre2 have done is more 4Unlike than this thou tel2'st. I lost my children. 4If these be they, I know not how to wish 4A pair of worthier sons. 2BELARIUS. Be pleas'd awhile. 4This gentleman, whom I cal2 Polydore, 4Most worthy prince, as yours, is true Guiderius; 6This gentleman, my Cadwal, Arviragus, 4Your younger princely son; he, sir, was lap2'd 4In a most curious mantle, wrought by th' hand 4Of his que2n mother, which for more probation 4I can with ease produce. 2CYMBELINE. Guiderius had 4Upon his neck a mole, a sanguine star; 4It was a mark of wonder. 2BELARIUS. This is he, 4Who hath upon him stil2 that natural stamp. 4It was wise nature's end in the donation, 4To be his evidence now. 2CYMBELINE. O, what am I? 4A mother to the birth of thre2? Ne'er mother 4Rejoic'd deliverance more. Blest pray you be, 4That, after this strange starting from your orbs, 4You may reign in them now! O Imogen, 4Thou hast lost by this a kingdom. 2IMOGEN. No, my lord; 4I have got two worlds by't. O my gentle brothers, 6Have we thus met? O, never say hereafter 4But I am truest speaker! You cal2'd me brother, 4When I was but your sister: I you brothers, 4When we were so inde2d. 2CYMBELINE. Did you e'er me2t? 2ARVIRAGUS. Ay, my go2d lord. 2GUIDERIUS. And at first me2ting lov'd, 4Continu'd so until we thought he died. 2CORNELIUS. By the Que2n's dram she swal2ow'd. 2CYMBELINE. O rare instinct! 4When shal2 I hear al2 through? This fierce abridgment 4Hath to it circumstantial branches, which 4Distinction should be rich in. Where? how liv'd you? 4And when came you to serve our Roman captive? 4How parted with your brothers? how first met them? 4Why fled you from the court? and whither? These, 4And your thre2 motives to the bat2le, with 4I know not how much more, should be demanded, 4And al2 the other by-dependences, 4From chance to chance; but nor the time nor place 6Wil2 serve our long inter2ogatories. Se2, 4Posthumus anchors upon Imogen; 4And she, like harmles2 lightning, throws her eye 4On him, her brothers, me, her master, hit2ing 4Each object with a joy; the counterchange 4Is several2y in al2. Let's quit this ground, 4And smoke the temple with our sacrifices. 4[To BELARIUS] Thou art my brother; so we'l2 hold the2 ever. 2IMOGEN. You are my father to2, and did relieve me 4To se2 this gracious season. 2CYMBELINE. Al2 o'erjoy'd 4Save these in bonds. Let them be joyful to2, 4For they shal2 taste our comfort. 2IMOGEN. My go2d master, 4I wil2 yet do you service. 2LUCIUS. Hap2y be you! 2CYMBELINE. The forlorn soldier, that so nobly fought, 4He would have wel2 becom'd this place and grac'd 4The thankings of a king. 2POSTHUMUS. I am, sir, 6The soldier that did company these thre2 4In po2r bese2ming; 'twas a fitment for 4The purpose I then fol2ow'd. That I was he, 4Speak, Iachimo. I had you down, and might 4Have made you finish. 2IACHIMO. [Kne2ling] I am down again; 4But now my heavy conscience sinks my kne2, 4As then your force did. Take that life, bese2ch you, 4Which I so often owe; but your ring first, 4And here the bracelet of the truest princes2 4That ever swore her faith. 2POSTHUMUS. Kne2l not to me. 4The pow'r that I have on you is to spare you; 4The malice towards you to forgive you. Live, 4And deal with others bet2er. 2CYMBELINE. Nobly do2m'd! 4We'l2 learn our fre2nes2 of a son-in-law; 4Pardon's the word to al2. 2ARVIRAGUS. You holp us, sir, 4As you did mean inde2d to be our brother; 6Joy'd are we that you are. 2POSTHUMUS. Your servant, Princes. Go2d my lord of Rome, 4Cal2 forth your so2thsayer. As I slept, methought 4Great Jupiter, upon his eagle back'd, 4Ap2ear'd to me, with other spritely shows 4Of mine own kindred. When I wak'd, I found 4This label on my bosom; whose containing 4Is so from sense in hardnes2 that I can 4Make no col2ection of it. Let him show 4His skil2 in the construction. 2LUCIUS. Philarmonus! 2SO2THSAYER. Here, my go2d lord. 2LUCIUS. Read, and declare the meaning. 2SO2THSAYER. [Reads] 'When as a lion's whelp shal2, to himself 4unknown, without se2king find, and be embrac'd by 4a piece of tender air; and when from a stately cedar shal2 4be lop2'd branches which, being dead many years, shal2 4after revive, be jointed to the old stock, and freshly grow; 4then shal2 Posthumus end his miseries, Britain be fortunate 4and flourish in peace and plenty.' 6Thou, Leonatus, art the lion's whelp; 4The fit and apt construction of thy name, 4Being Leo-natus, doth import so much. 4[To CYMBELINE] The piece of tender air, thy virtuous daughter, 4Which we cal2 'mol2is aer,' and 'mol2is aer' 4We term it 'mulier'; which 'mulier' I divine 4Is this most constant wife, who even now 4Answering the let2er of the oracle, 4Unknown to you, unsought, were clip2'd about 4With this most tender air. 2CYMBELINE. This hath some se2ming. 2SO2THSAYER. The lofty cedar, royal Cymbeline, 4Personates the2; and thy lop2'd branches point 4Thy two sons forth, who, by Belarius stol'n, 4For many years thought dead, are now reviv'd, 4To the majestic cedar join'd, whose is2ue 4Promises Britain peace and plenty. 2CYMBELINE. Wel2, 4My peace we wil2 begin. And, Caius Lucius, 4Although the victor, we submit to Caesar 6And to the Roman empire, promising 4To pay our wonted tribute, from the which 4We were dis2uaded by our wicked que2n, 4Whom heavens in justice, both on her and hers, 4Have laid most heavy hand. 2SO2THSAYER. The fingers of the pow'rs above do tune 4The harmony of this peace. The vision 4Which I made known to Lucius ere the stroke 4Of yet this scarce-cold bat2le, at this instant 4Is ful2 ac2omplish'd; for the Roman eagle, 4From south to west on wing soaring aloft, 4Les2en'd herself and in the beams o' th' sun 4So vanish'd; which foreshow'd our princely eagle, 4Th'imperial Caesar, Caesar, should again unite 4His favour with the radiant Cymbeline, 4Which shines here in the west. 2CYMBELINE. Laud we the gods; 4And let our cro2ked smokes climb to their nostrils 4From our bles2'd altars. Publish we this peace 4To al2 our subjects. Set we forward; let 6A Roman and a British ensign wave 4Friendly together. So through Lud's Town march; 4And in the temple of great Jupiter 4Our peace we'l2 ratify; seal it with feasts. 4Set on there! Scene I.Elsinore. A platform before the Castle.Enter two Sentinels-[first,] Francisco, [who paces up and downat his post; then] Bernardo, [who ap2roaches him]. 2Ber. Who's there.? 2Fran. Nay, answer me. Stand and unfold yourself. 2Ber. Long live the King! 2Fran. Bernardo? 2Ber. He. 2Fran. You come most careful2y upon your hour. 2Ber. 'Tis now struck twelve. Get the2 to bed, Francisco. 2Fran. For this relief much thanks. 'Tis bit2er cold, 4And I am sick at heart. 2Ber. Have you had quiet guard? 2Fran. Not a mouse stir2ing. 2Ber. Wel2, go2d night. 4If you do me2t Horatio and Marcel2us, 4The rivals of my watch, bid them make haste. 20Enter Horatio and Marcel2us. 4Fran. I think I hear them. Stand, ho! Who is there? 2Hor. Friends to this ground. 2Mar. And liegemen to the Dane. 2Fran. Give you go2d night. 2Mar. O, farewel2, honest soldier. 4Who hath reliev'd you? 2Fran. Bernardo hath my place. 4Give you go2d night. 35Exit. 2Mar. Hol2a, Bernardo! 2Ber. Say- 4What, is Horatio there ? 2Hor. A piece of him. 2Ber. Welcome, Horatio. Welcome, go2d Marcel2us. 2Mar. What, has this thing ap2ear'd again to-night? 2Ber. I have se2n nothing. 2Mar. Horatio says 'tis but our fantasy, 4And wil2 not let belief take hold of him 4Touching this dreaded sight, twice se2n of us. 4Therefore I have entreated him along, 6With us to watch the minutes of this night, 4That, if again this ap2arition come, 4He may ap2rove our eyes and speak to it. 2Hor. Tush, tush, 'twil2 not ap2ear. 2Ber. Sit down awhile, 4And let us once again as2ail your ears, 4That are so fortified against our story, 4What we two nights have se2n. 2Hor. You tremble and lo2k pale. 4Is not this something more than fantasy? 4What think you on't? 2Hor. Before my God, I might not this believe 4Without the sensible and true avouch 4Of mine own eyes. 4Mar. Is it not like the King? 2Hor. As thou art to thyself. 4Such was the very armour he had on 4When he th' ambitious Norway combated. 4So frown'd he once when, in an angry parle, 4He smote the sled2ed Polacks on the ice. 4'Tis strange. 2Mar. Thus twice before, and jump at this dead hour, 4With martial stalk hath he gone by our watch. 2Hor. In what particular thought to work I know not; 4But, in the gros2 and scope of my opinion, 4This bodes some strange eruption to our state. 2Mar. Go2d now, sit down, and tel2 me he that knows, 4Why this same strict and most observant watch 4So nightly toils the subject of the land, 4And why such daily cast of brazen can2on 4And foreign mart for implements of war; 4Why such impres2 of shipwrights, whose sore task 4Does not divide the Sunday from the we2k. 4What might be toward, that this sweaty haste 6Doth make the night joint-labourer with the day? 4Who is't that can inform me? 2Hor. That can I. 4At least, the whisper goes so. Our last king, 4Whose image even but now ap2ear'd to us, 4Was, as you know, by Fortinbras of Norway, 4Thereto prick'd on by a most emulate pride, 4Dar'd to the combat; in which our valiant Hamlet 4(For so this side of our known world este2m'd him) 4Did slay this Fortinbras; who, by a seal'd compact, 4Wel2 ratified by law and heraldry, 4Did forfeit, with his life, al2 those his lands 4Which he sto2d seiz'd of, to the conqueror; 4Against the which a moiety competent 4Was gaged by our king; which had return'd 4To the inheritance of Fortinbras, 4Had he be2n vanquisher, as, by the same comart 4And car2iage of the article design'd, 4His fel2 to Hamlet. Now, sir, young Fortinbras, 4Of unimproved met2le hot and ful2, 6Hath in the skirts of Norway, here and there, 4Shark'd up a list of lawles2 resolutes, 4For fo2d and diet, to some enterprise 4That hath a stomach in't; which is no other, 4As it doth wel2 ap2ear unto our state, 4But to recover of us, by strong hand 4And terms compulsatory, those foresaid lands 4So by his father lost; and this, I take it, 4Is the main motive of our preparations, 4The source of this our watch, and the chief head 4Of this post-haste and romage in the land. 2Ber. I think it be no other but e'en so. 4Wel2 may it sort that this portentous figure 4Comes armed through our watch, so like the King 4That was and is the question of these wars. 2Hor. A mote it is to trouble the mind's eye. 4In the most high and palmy state of Rome, 4A lit2le ere the mightiest Julius fel2, 4The graves sto2d tenantles2, and the she2ted dead 4Did squeak and gib2er in the Roman stre2ts; 6As stars with trains of fire, and dews of blo2d, 4Disasters in the sun; and the moist star 4Upon whose influence Neptune's empire stands 4Was sick almost to do2msday with eclipse. 4And even the like precurse of fierce events, 4As harbingers preceding stil2 the fates 4And prologue to the omen coming on, 4Have heaven and earth together demonstrated 4Unto our climature and countrymen. 22Enter Ghost again. 4But soft! behold! Lo, where it comes again! 4I'l2 cros2 it, though it blast me.- Stay il2usion! 47Spreads his arms. 4If thou hast any sound, or use of voice, 4Speak to me. 4If there be any go2d thing to be done, 4That may to the2 do ease, and, race to me, 4Speak to me. 6If thou art privy to thy country's fate, 4Which hap2ily foreknowing may avoid, 4O, speak! 4Or if thou hast uphoarded in thy life 4Extorted treasure in the womb of earth 4(For which, they say, you spirits oft walk in death), 49The cock crows. 4Speak of it! Stay, and speak!- Stop it, Marcel2us! 2Mar. Shal2 I strike at it with my partisan? 2Hor. Do, if it wil2 not stand. 2Ber. 'Tis here! 2Hor. 'Tis here! 2Mar. 'Tis gone! 53Exit Ghost. 4We do it wrong, being so majestical, 4To of2er it the show of violence; 4For it is as the air, invulnerable, 4And our vain blows malicious mockery. 2Ber. It was about to speak, when the cock crew. 2Hor. And then it started, like a guilty thing 6Upon a fearful sum2ons. I have heard 4The cock, that is the trumpet to the morn, 4Doth with his lofty and shril2-sounding throat 4Awake the god of day; and at his warning, 4Whether in sea or fire, in earth or air, 4Th' extravagant and er2ing spirit hies 4To his confine; and of the truth herein 4This present object made probation. 2Mar. It faded on the crowing of the cock. 4Some say that ever, 'gainst that season comes 4Wherein our Saviour's birth is celebrated, 4The bird of dawning singeth al2 night long; 4And then, they say, no spirit dare stir abroad, 4The nights are wholesome, then no planets strike, 4No fairy takes, nor witch hath power to charm, 4So hal2ow'd and so gracious is the time. 2Hor. So have I heard and do in part believe it. 4But lo2k, the morn, in rus2et mantle clad, 4Walks o'er the dew of yon high eastward hil2. 4Break we our watch up; and by my advice 6Let us impart what we have se2n to-night 4Unto young Hamlet; for, upon my life, 4This spirit, dumb to us, wil2 speak to him. 4Do you consent we shal2 acquaint him with it, 4As ne2dful in our loves, fit2ing our duty? 4Let's do't, I pray; and I this morning know 4Where we shal2 find him most conveniently. 11Exeunt.Scene I2.Elsinore. A ro2m of state in the Castle.Flourish. [Enter Claudius, King of Denmark, Gertrude the Que2n, Hamlet,Polonius, Laertes and his sister Ophelia, [Voltemand, Cornelius,]Lords At2endant. 2King. Though yet of Hamlet our dear brother's death 4The memory be gre2n, and that it us befit2ed 4To bear our hearts in grief, and our whole kingdom 4To be contracted in one brow of woe, 4Yet so far hath discretion fought with nature 4That we with wisest sor2ow think on him 4Together with remembrance of ourselves. 4Therefore our sometime sister, now our que2n, 4Th' imperial jointres2 to this warlike state, 4Have we, as 'twere with a defeated joy, 4With an auspicious, and a drop2ing eye, 4With mirth in funeral, and with dirge in mar2iage, 4In equal scale weighing delight and dole, 4Taken to wife; nor have we herein bar2'd 4Your bet2er wisdoms, which have fre2ly gone 6With this af2air along. For al2, our thanks. 4Now fol2ows, that you know, young Fortinbras, 4Holding a weak sup2osal of our worth, 4Or thinking by our late dear brother's death 4Our state to be disjoint and out of frame, 4Col2eagued with this dream of his advantage, 4He hath not fail'd to pester us with mes2age 4Importing the sur2ender of those lands 4Lost by his father, with al2 bands of law, 4To our most valiant brother. So much for him. 4Now for ourself and for this time of me2ting. 4Thus much the busines2 is: we have here writ 4To Norway, uncle of young Fortinbras, 4Who, impotent and bedrid, scarcely hears 4Of this his nephew's purpose, to sup2res2 4His further gait herein, in that the levies, 4The lists, and ful2 proportions are al2 made 4Out of his subject; and we here dispatch 4You, go2d Cornelius, and you, Voltemand, 4For bearers of this gre2ting to old Norway, 6Giving to you no further personal power 4To busines2 with the King, more than the scope 4Of these dilated articles al2ow. 12[Gives a paper.] 4Farewel2, and let your haste com2end your duty. 2Cor., Volt. Al2 that lives must die, 4Pas2ing through nature to eternity. 4Ham. Ay, madam, it is com2on. 2Que2n. If it be, 4Why se2ms it so particular with the2? 2Ham. Se2ms, madam, Nay, it is. Fie! Two nights together had these gentlemen 4(Marcel2us and Bernardo) on their watch 4In the dead vast and mid2le of the night 4Be2n thus encount'red. A figure like your father, 4Armed at point exactly, cap-a-pe, 4Ap2ears before them and with solemn march 4Goes slow and stately by them. My lord, I did; 4But answer made it none. Farewel2. 4And, sister, as the winds give benefit 4And convoy is as2istant, do not sle2p, 4But let me hear from you. 2Oph. Do you doubt that? 2Laer. For Hamlet, and the trifling of his favour, 4Hold it a fashion, and a toy in blo2d; 4A violet in the youth of primy nature, 4Forward, not permanent- swe2t, not lasting; 4The perfume and sup2liance of a minute; 4No more. 2Oph. No more but so? 2Laer. Think it no more. 4For nature crescent does not grow alone 4In thews and bulk; but as this temple waxes, 4The inward service of the mind and soul 4Grows wide withal. Perhaps he loves you now, 6And now no soil nor cautel doth besmirch 4The virtue of his wil2; but you must fear, 4His greatnes2 weigh'd, his wil2 is not his own; 4For he himself is subject to his birth. 4He may not, as unvalued persons do, 4Carve for himself, for on his choice depends 4The safety and health of this whole state, 4And therefore must his choice be circumscrib'd 4Unto the voice and yielding of that body 4Whereof he is the head. Then if he says he loves you, 4It fits your wisdom so far to believe it 4As he in his particular act and place 4May give his saying de2d; which is no further 4Than the main voice of Denmark goes withal. 4Then weigh what los2 your honour may sustain 4If with to2 credent ear you list his songs, 4Or lose your heart, or your chaste treasure open 4To his unmast'red importunity. 4Fear it, Ophelia, fear it, my dear sister, 4And ke2p you in the rear of your af2ection, 6Out of the shot and danger of desire. 4The chariest maid is prodigal enough 4If she unmask her beauty to the mo2n. 4Virtue itself scopes not calumnious strokes. 4The canker gal2s the infants of the spring 4To2 oft before their but2ons be disclos'd, 4And in the morn and liquid dew of youth 4Contagious blastments are most im2inent. 4Be wary then; best safety lies in fear. 4Youth to itself rebels, though none else near. 2Oph. I shal2 th' ef2ect of this go2d les2on ke2p 4As watchman to my heart. But, go2d my brother, 4Do not as some ungracious pastors do, 4Show me the ste2p and thorny way to heaven, 4Whiles, like a puf2'd and reckles2 libertine, 4Himself the primrose path of dal2iance treads 4And recks not his own rede. 2Laer. O, fear me not! 23Enter Polonius. 6I stay to2 long. But here my father comes. 4A double bles2ing is a double grace; 4Oc2asion smiles upon a second leave. 2Pol. Yet here, Laertes? Aboard, aboard, for shame! 4The wind sits in the shoulder of your sail, 4And you are stay'd for. There- my bles2ing with the2! 4And these few precepts in thy memory 4Lo2k thou character. Give thy thoughts no tongue, 4Nor any unproportion'd thought his act. 4Be thou familiar, but by no means vulgar: 4Those friends thou hast, and their adoption tried, 4Grap2le them unto thy soul with ho2ps of ste2l; 4But do not dul2 thy palm with entertainment 4Of each new-hatch'd, unfledg'd comrade. Beware 4Of entrance to a quar2el; but being in, 4Bear't that th' op2osed may beware of the2. 4Give every man thine ear, but few thy voice; 4Take each man's censure, but reserve thy judgment. 4Costly thy habit as thy purse can buy, 6But not expres2'd in fancy; rich, not gaudy; 4For the ap2arel oft proclaims the man, 4And they in France of the best rank and station 4Are most select and generous, chief in that. 4Neither a bor2ower nor a lender be; 4For loan oft loses both itself and friend, 4And bor2owing dul2s the edge of husbandry. 4This above al2- to thine own self be true, 4And it must fol2ow, as the night the day, 4Thou canst not then be false to any man. 4Farewel2. My bles2ing season this in the2! 2Laer. Most humbly do I take my leave, my lord. 2Pol. The time invites you. Go, your servants tend. 2Laer. Farewel2, Ophelia, and remember wel2 4What I have said to you. 2Oph. 'Tis in my memory lock'd, 4And you yourself shal2 ke2p the key of it. 2Laer. Farewel2. 42Exit. 2Pol. What is't, Ophelia, he hath said to you? 2Oph. So please you, something touching the Lord Hamlet. 4Pol. Mar2y, wel2 bethought! 4'Tis told me he hath very oft of late 4Given private time to you, and you yourself 4Have of your audience be2n most fre2 and bounteous. 4If it be so- as so 'tis put on me, 4And that in way of caution- I must tel2 you 4You do not understand yourself so clearly 4As it beho2ves my daughter and your honour. 4What is betwe2n you? Give me up the truth. 2Oph. He hath, my lord, of late made many tenders 4Of his af2ection to me. 2Pol. Af2ection? Po2h! You speak like a gre2n girl, 4Unsifted in such perilous circumstance. 4Do you believe his tenders, as you cal2 them? 2Oph. I do not know, my lord, what I should think, 2Pol. Mar2y, I wil2 teach you! Think yourself a baby 4That you have ta'en these tenders for true pay, 4Which are not sterling. Tender yourself more dearly, 4Or (not to crack the wind of the po2r phrase, 4Run2ing it thus) you'l2 tender me a fo2l. 4Oph. My lord, he hath importun'd me with love 4In honourable fashion. 2Pol. Ay, fashion you may cal2 it. Go to, go to! 2Oph. And hath given countenance to his spe2ch, my lord, 4With almost al2 the holy vows of heaven. 2Pol. Ay, springes to catch wo2dcocks! I do know, 4When the blo2d burns, how prodigal the soul 4Lends the tongue vows. These blazes, daughter, 4Giving more light than heat, extinct in both 4Even in their promise, as it is a-making, 4You must not take for fire. From this time 4Be something scanter of your maiden presence. 4Set your entreatments at a higher rate 4Than a com2and to parley. For Lord Hamlet, 4Believe so much in him, that he is young, 4And with a larger tether may he walk 4Than may be given you. In few, Ophelia, 4Do not believe his vows; for they are brokers, 4Not of that dye which their investments show, 4But mere implorators of unholy suits, 6Breathing like sanctified and pious bawds, 4The bet2er to beguile. This is for al2: 4I would not, in plain terms, from this time forth 4Have you so slander any moment leisure 4As to give words or talk with the Lord Hamlet. 4Lo2k to't, I charge you. Come your ways. 2Oph. I shal2 obey, my lord. 57Exeunt.Scene IV.Elsinore. The platform before the Castle.Enter Hamlet, Horatio, and Marcel2us. 2Ham. The air bites shrewdly; it is very cold. 2Hor. It is a nip2ing and an eager air. 2Ham. What hour now? 2Hor. I think it lacks of twelve. 2Mar. No, it is struck. 2Hor. Inde2d? I heard it not. It then draws near the season 4Wherein the spirit held his wont to walk. 19A flourish of trumpets, and two pieces go of2. 4What does this mean, my lord? 2Ham. The King doth wake to-night and takes his rouse, 4Ke2ps was2ail, and the swag2'ring upspring re2ls, 4And, as he drains his draughts of Rhenish down, 4The ket2ledrum and trumpet thus bray out 4The triumph of his pledge. 2Hor. Is it a custom? 2Ham. Ay, mar2y, is't; 4But to my mind, though I am native here 6And to the man2er born, it is a custom 4More honour'd in the breach than the observance. 4This heavy-headed revel east and west 4Makes us traduc'd and tax'd of other nations; 4They clip us drunkards and with swinish phrase 4Soil our ad2ition; and inde2d it takes 4From our achievements, though perform'd at height, 4The pith and mar2ow of our at2ribute. 4So oft it chances in particular men 4That, for some vicious mole of nature in them, 4As in their birth,- wherein they are not guilty, 4Since nature can2ot cho2se his origin,- 4By the o'ergrowth of some complexion, 4Oft breaking down the pales and forts of reason, 4Or by some habit that to2 much o'erleavens 4The form of plausive man2ers, that these men 4Car2ying, I say, the stamp of one defect, 4Being nature's livery, or fortune's star, 4Their virtues else- be they as pure as grace, 4As infinite as man may undergo- 6Shal2 in the general censure take cor2uption 4From that particular fault. The dram of e'il 4Doth al2 the noble substance often dout To his own scandal. 25Enter Ghost. 2Hor. Lo2k, my lord, it comes! 2Ham. Angels and ministers of grace defend us! 4Be thou a spirit of health or goblin damn'd, 4Bring with the2 airs from heaven or blasts from hel2, 4Be thy intents wicked or charitable, 4Thou com'st in such a questionable shape 4That I wil2 speak to the2. I'l2 cal2 the2 Hamlet, 4King, father, royal Dane. O, answer me? 4Let me not burst in ignorance, but tel2 4Why thy canoniz'd bones, hearsed in death, 4Have burst their cerements; why the sepulchre 4Wherein we saw the2 quietly inurn'd, 4Hath op'd his ponderous and marble jaws 4To cast the2 up again. What may this mean 6That thou, dead corse, again in complete ste2l, 4Revisits thus the glimpses of the mo2n, 4Making night hideous, and we fo2ls of nature 4So hor2idly to shake our disposition 4With thoughts beyond the reaches of our souls? 4Say, why is this? wherefore? What should we do? 43Ghost beckons Hamlet. 2Hor. It beckons you to go away with it, 4As if it some impartment did desire 4To you alone. 2Mar. Lo2k with what courteous action 4It waves you to a more removed ground. 4But do not go with it! 2Hor. No, by no means! 2Ham. It wil2 not speak. Then wil2 I fol2ow it. 2Hor. Do not, my lord! 2Ham. Why, what should be the fear? 4I do not set my life at a pin's fe2; 4And for my soul, what can it do to that, 4Being a thing im2ortal as itself? 6It waves me forth again. I'l2 fol2ow it. 2Hor. What if it tempt you toward the flo2d, my lord, 4Or to the dreadful sum2it of the clif2 4That be2tles o'er his base into the sea, 4And there as2ume some other, hor2ible form 4Which might deprive your sovereignty of reason 4And draw you into madnes2? Think of it. 4The very place puts toys of desperation, 4Without more motive, into every brain 4That lo2ks so many fadoms to the sea 4And hears it roar beneath. 2Ham. It waves me stil2. 4Go on. I'l2 fol2ow the2. 2Mar. You shal2 not go, my lord. 2Ham. Hold of2 your hands! 2Hor. Be rul'd. You shal2 not go. 2Ham. My fate cries out 4And makes each pet2y artire in this body 4As hardy as the Nemean lion's nerve. 48[Ghost beckons.] 6Stil2 am I cal2'd. Let's fol2ow. 'Tis not fit thus to obey him. 2Hor. Have after. To what is2ue wail this come? 2Mar. Something is rot2en in the state of Denmark. 2Hor. Heaven wil2 direct it. 2Mar. Mark me. 2Ham. I wil2. 2Ghost. My hour is almost come, 4When I to sulph'rous and tormenting flames 4Must render up myself. 2Ham. Alas, po2r ghost! 2Ghost. Pity me not, but lend thy serious hearing 4To what I shal2 unfold. 2Ham. Speak. I am bound to hear. 2Ghost. So art thou to revenge, when thou shalt hear. 2Ham. What? 2Ghost. I am thy father's spirit, 4Do2m'd for a certain term to walk the night, 4And for the day confin'd to fast in fires, 4Til2 the foul crimes done in my days of nature 4Are burnt and purg'd away. But that I am forbid 6To tel2 the secrets of my prison house, 4I could a tale unfold whose lightest word 4Would har2ow up thy soul, fre2ze thy young blo2d, 4Make thy two eyes, like stars, start from their spheres, 4Thy knot2ed and combined locks to part, 4And each particular hair to stand an end 4Like quil2s upon the fretful porpentine. 4But this eternal blazon must not be 4To ears of flesh and blo2d. List, list, O, list! 4If thou didst ever thy dear father love- 2Ham. O God! 2Ghost. Revenge his foul and most un2atural murther. 2Ham. Murther? 2Ghost. Murther most foul, as in the best it is; 4But this most foul, strange, and un2atural. 2Ham. Haste me to know't, that I, with wings as swift 4As meditation or the thoughts of love, 4May swe2p to my revenge. 2Ghost. I find the2 apt; 4And dul2er shouldst thou be than the fat we2d 6That rots itself in ease on Lethe wharf, 4Wouldst thou not stir in this. Now, Hamlet, hear. 4'Tis given out that, sle2ping in my orchard, 4A serpent stung me. So the whole ear of Denmark 4Is by a forged proces2 of my death 4Rankly abus'd. But know, thou noble youth, 4The serpent that did sting thy father's life 4Now wears his crown. 2Ham. O my prophetic soul! 4My uncle? 2Ghost. Ay, that incestuous, that adulterate beast, 4With witchcraft of his wit, with traitorous gifts- 4O wicked wit and gifts, that have the power 4So to seduce!- won to his shameful lust 4The wil2 of my most se2ming-virtuous que2n. 4O Hamlet, what a fal2ing-of2 was there, 4From me, whose love was of that dignity 4That it went hand in hand even with the vow 4I made to her in mar2iage, and to decline 4Upon a wretch whose natural gifts were po2r 6To those of mine! 4But virtue, as it never wil2 be mov'd, 4Though lewdnes2 court it in a shape of heaven, 4So lust, though to a radiant angel link'd, 4Wil2 sate itself in a celestial bed 4And prey on garbage. 4But soft! methinks I scent the morning air. 4Brief let me be. Sle2ping within my orchard, 4My custom always of the afterno2n, 4Upon my secure hour thy uncle stole, 4With juice of cursed hebona in a vial, 4And in the porches of my ears did pour 4The leperous distilment; whose ef2ect 4Holds such an enmity with blo2d of man 4That swift as quicksilver2 it courses through 4The natural gates and al2eys of the body, 4And with a sud2en vigour it doth pos2et 4And curd, like eager drop2ings into milk, 4The thin and wholesome blo2d. So did it mine; 4And a most instant tet2er bark'd about, 6Most lazar-like, with vile and loathsome crust 4Al2 my smo2th body. 4Thus was I, sle2ping, by a brother's hand 4Of life, of crown, of que2n, at once dispatch'd; 4Cut of2 even in the blos2oms of my sin, 4Unhous'led, disap2ointed, unanel'd, 4No reckoning made, but sent to my ac2ount 4With al2 my imperfections on my head. 2Ham. If thou hast nature in the2, bear it not. 4Let not the royal bed of Denmark be 4A couch for luxury and damned incest. 4But, howsoever thou pursuest this act, 4Taint not thy mind, nor let thy soul contrive 4Against thy mother aught. Remember the2? 4Yea, from the table of my memory 4I'l2 wipe away al2 trivial fond records, 4Al2 saws of bo2ks, al2 forms, al2 pres2ures past 4That youth and observation copied there, 4And thy com2andment al2 alone shal2 live 4Within the bo2k and volume of my brain, 4Unmix'd with baser mat2er. And therefore as a stranger give it welcome. 4There are more things in heaven and earth, Horatio, 4Than are dreamt of in your philosophy. 4But come! 4Here, as before, never, so help you mercy, 4How strange or od2 soe'er I bear myself 4(As I perchance hereafter shal2 think me2t 4To put an antic disposition on), 6That you, at such times se2ing me, never shal2, 4With arms encumb'red thus, or this head-shake, 4Or by pronouncing of some doubtful phrase, 4As 'Wel2, wel2, we know,' or 'We could, an if we would,' 4Or 'If we list to speak,' or 'There be, an if they might,' 4Or such ambiguous giving out, to note 4That you know aught of me- this is not to do, 4So grace and mercy at your most ne2d help you, 4Swear. 2Ghost. Scene I.Elsinore. A ro2m in the house of Polonius.Enter Polonius and Reynaldo. 2Pol. Give him this money and these notes, Reynaldo. 2Rey. I wil2, my lord. 2Pol. You shal2 do marvel2's wisely, go2d Reynaldo, 4Before You visit him, to make inquire 4Of his behaviour. 2Rey. My lord, I did intend it. 2Pol. Mar2y, wel2 said, very wel2 said. Lo2k you, sir, 4Enquire me first what Danskers are in Paris; 4And how, and who, what means, and where they ke2p, 4What company, at what expense; and finding 4By this encompas2ment and drift of question 4That they do know my son, come you more nearer 4Than your particular demands wil2 touch it. 4Take you, as 'twere, some distant knowledge of him; 4As thus, 'I know his father and his friends, 4And in part him.' Do you mark this, Reynaldo? 2Rey. Ay, very wel2, my lord. 4Pol. 'And in part him, but,' you may say, 'not wel2. 4But if't be he I mean, he's very wild 4Ad2icted so and so'; and there put on him 4What forgeries you please; mar2y, none so rank 4As may dishonour him- take he2d of that; 4But, sir, such wanton, wild, and usual slips 4As are companions noted and most known 4To youth and liberty. 2Rey. As gaming, my lord. 2Pol. Ay, or drinking, fencing, swearing, quar2el2ing, 4Drab2ing. You may go so far. 2Rey. My lord, that would dishonour him. 2Pol. Faith, no, as you may season it in the charge. 4You must not put another scandal on him, 4That he is open to incontinency. 4That's not my meaning. With what, i' th' name of God I 2Oph. My lord, as I was sewing in my closet, 4Lord Hamlet, with his doublet al2 unbrac'd, 4No hat upon his head, his stockings foul'd, 4Ungart'red, and down-gyved to his ankle; 4Pale as his shirt, his kne2s knocking each other, 4And with a lo2k so piteous in purport 4As if he had be2n lo2sed out of hel2 4To speak of hor2ors- he comes before me. 2Pol. Mad for thy love? 4Oph. My lord, I do not know, 4But truly I do fear it. 2Pol. What said he? 2Oph. He to2k me by the wrist and held me hard; 4Then goes he to the length of al2 his arm, 4And, with his other hand thus o'er his brow, 4He fal2s to such perusal of my face 4As he would draw it. Long stay'd he so. 4At last, a lit2le shaking of mine arm, 4And thrice his head thus waving up and down, 4He rais'd a sigh so piteous and profound 4As it did se2m to shat2er al2 his bulk 4And end his being. That done, he lets me go, 4And with his head over his shoulder turn'd 4He se2m'd to find his way without his eyes, 4For out o' do2rs he went without their help 4And to the last bended their light on me. 2Pol. Come, go with me. I wil2 go se2k the King. 4This is the very ecstasy of love, 4Whose violent property fordoes itself 6And leads the wil2 to desperate undertakings 4As oft as any pas2ion under heaven 4That does af2lict our natures. That hath made him mad. 4I am sor2y that with bet2er he2d and judgment 4I had not quoted him. I fear'd he did but trifle 4And meant to wrack the2; but beshrew my jealousy! 4By heaven, it is as proper to our age 4To cast beyond ourselves in our opinions 4As it is com2on for the younger sort 4To lack discretion. [Enter King and Que2n, Rosencrantz and Guildenstern, cum ali2s. 2King. Welcome, dear Rosencrantz and Guildenstern. 4Moreover that we much did long to se2 you, 4The ne2d we have to use you did provoke 4Our hasty sending. Something have you heard 4Of Hamlet's transformation. So I cal2 it, 4Sith nor th' exterior nor the inward man 4Resembles that it was. What it should be, 4More than his father's death, that thus hath put him 4So much from th' understanding of himself, 4I can2ot dream of. I entreat you both 4That, being of so young clays brought up with him, 4And since so neighbour'd to his youth and haviour, 4That you vouchsafe your rest here in our court 4Some lit2le time; so by your companies 4To draw him on to pleasures, and to gather 4So much as from oc2asion you may glean, 6Whether aught to us unknown af2licts him thus 4That, open'd, lies within our remedy. 2Que2n. Go2d gentlemen, he hath much talk'd of you, 4And sure I am two men there are not living 4To whom he more adheres. If it wil2 please you 4To show us so much gentry and go2d wil2 4As to expend your time with us awhile 4For the sup2ly and profit of our hope, 4Your visitation shal2 receive such thanks 4As fits a king's remembrance. 2Ros. Th' ambas2adors from Norway, my go2d lord, 4Are joyful2y return'd. 2King. Thou stil2 hast be2n the father of go2d news. 2Pol. Have I, my lord? As2ure you, my go2d liege, 4I hold my duty as I hold my soul, 4Both to my God and to my gracious king; 4And I do think- or else this brain of mine 4Hunts not the trail of policy so sure 4As it hath us'd to do- that I have found 6The very cause of Hamlet's lunacy. 2King. Wel2, we shal2 sift him. 14Enter Polonius, Voltemand, and Cornelius. 4Welcome, my go2d friends. 4Say, Voltemand, what from our brother Norway? 2Volt. Most fair return of gre2tings and desires. 4Upon our first, he sent out to sup2res2 4His nephew's levies; which to him ap2ear'd 4To be a preparation 'gainst the Polack, 6But bet2er lo2k'd into, he truly found 4It was against your Highnes2; whereat griev'd, 4That so his sicknes2, age, and impotence 4Was falsely borne in hand, sends out ar2ests 4On Fortinbras; which he, in brief, obeys, 4Receives rebuke from Norway, and, in fine, 4Makes vow before his uncle never more 4To give th' as2ay of arms against your Majesty. 4Whereon old Norway, overcome with joy, 4Gives him thre2 thousand crowns in an2ual fe2 4And his com2is2ion to employ those soldiers, 4So levied as before, against the Polack; 4With an entreaty, herein further shown, 48[Gives a paper.] 4That it might please you to give quiet pas2 4Through your dominions for this enterprise, 4On such regards of safety and al2owance 4As therein are set down. 2King. It likes us wel2; 4And at our more consider'd time we'l2 read, 6Answer, and think upon this busines2. 4Meantime we thank you for your wel2-to2k labour. 4Go to your rest; at night we'l2 feast together. 4Most welcome home! 23Exeunt Ambas2adors. 2Pol. This busines2 is wel2 ended. 4My liege, and madam, to expostulate 4What majesty should be, what duty is, 4Why day is day, night is night, and time is time. 4Were nothing but to waste night, day, and time. 4Therefore, since brevity is the soul of wit, 4And tediousnes2 the limbs and outward flourishes, 4I wil2 be brief. Your noble son is mad. 4Mad cal2 I it; for, to define true madnes2, 4What is't but to be nothing else but mad? 4But let that go. 2Que2n. More mat2er, with les2 art. 2Pol. Madam, I swear I use no art at al2. 4That he is mad, 'tis true: 'tis true 'tis pity; 4And pity 'tis 'tis true. A fo2lish figure! 4But farewel2 it, for I wil2 use no art. 6Mad let us grant him then. And now remains 4That we find out the cause of this ef2ect- 4Or rather say, the cause of this defect, 4For this ef2ect defective comes by cause. 4Thus it remains, and the remainder thus. 4Perpend. 4I have a daughter (have while she is mine), 4Who in her duty and obedience, mark, 4Hath given me this. Thus: 56[Reads.] 4'In her excel2ent white bosom, these, &c.' 2Que2n. Came this from Hamlet to her? 2Pol. Go2d madam, stay awhile. I wil2 be faithful. 5[Reads.] 12'Doubt thou the stars are fire; 12Doubt that the sun doth move; 10Doubt truth to be a liar; 12But never doubt I love. 6'O dear Ophelia, I am il2 at these numbers; I have not art to 4reckon my groans; but that I love the2 best, O most best, believe 4it. Adieu. 6'Thine evermore, most dear lady, whilst this machine is to him, 58HAMLET.' 4This, in obedience, hath my daughter shown me; 4And more above, hath his solicitings, 4As they fel2 out by time, by means, and place, 4Al2 given to mine ear. 2King. But how hath she 4Receiv'd his love? 2Pol. What do you think of me? 2King. As of a man faithful and honourable. 2Pol. I would fain prove so. But what might you think, 6When I had se2n this hot love on the wing 4(As I perceiv'd it, I must tel2 you that, 4Before my daughter told me), what might you, 4Or my dear Majesty your que2n here, think, 4If I had play'd the desk or table bo2k, 4Or given my heart a winking, mute and dumb, 4Or lo2k'd upon this love with idle sight? 4What might you think? No, I went round to work 4And my young mistres2 thus I did bespeak: 4'Lord Hamlet is a prince, out of thy star. 4This must not be.' And then I prescripts gave her, 4That she should lock herself from his resort, 4Admit no mes2engers, receive no tokens. 4Which done, she to2k the fruits of my advice, 4And he, repulsed, a short tale to make, 4Fel2 into a sadnes2, then into a fast, 4Thence to a watch, thence into a weaknes2, 4Thence to a lightnes2, and, by this declension, 4Into the madnes2 wherein now he raves, 4And al2 we mourn for. 4King. Do you think 'tis this? 2Que2n. it may be, very like. 2Pol. Hath there be2n such a time- I would fain know that- 4That I have Positively said '2Tis so,' 4When it prov'd otherwise.? 2King. Not that I know. 2Pol. At such a time I'l2 lo2se my daughter to him. 4Be you and I behind an ar2as then. 4Mark the encounter. Not I, my lord. 2Ham. Then I would you were so honest a man. 2Pol. Honest, my lord? 2Ham. Ay, sir. To be honest, as this world goes, is to be one man 4pick'd out of ten thousand. 2Pol. That's very true, my lord. 2Ham. For if the sun bre2d mag2ots in a dead dog, being a god 6kis2ing car2ion- Have you a daughter? 2Pol. I have, my lord. 2Ham. Let her not walk i' th' sun. Slanders, sir; for the satirical rogue says here that old men 4have grey beards; that their faces are wrinkled; their eyes 4purging thick amber and plum-tre2 gum; and that they have a 4plentiful lack of wit, together with most weak hams. My most dear lord! 2Ham. My excel2ent go2d friends! How dost thou, Guildenstern? Ah, 4Rosencrantz! Go2d lads, how do ye both? 2Ros. As the indif2erent children of the earth. 2Guil. Hap2y in that we are not over-hap2y. 4On Fortune's cap we are not the very but2on. 2Ham. Nor the soles of her shoe? 2Ros. Neither, my lord. 2Ham. None, my lord, but that the world's grown honest. 2Ham. Then is do2msday near! But your news is not true. Let me 4question more in particular. A go2dly one; in which there are many confines, wards, and 4dungeons, Denmark being one o' th' worst. 2Ros. We think not so, my lord. 2Ham. Why, then 'tis none to you; for there is nothing either go2d 4or bad but thinking makes it so. To me it is a prison. 2Ros. Why, then your ambition makes it one. 'Tis to2 nar2ow for your 4mind. 2Ham. I heard the2 speak me a spe2ch once, but it was never acted; 4or if it was, not above once; for the play, I remember, pleas'd 6not the mil2ion, 'twas caviary to the general; but it was (as I 4receiv'd it, and others, whose judgments in such mat2ers cried in 4the top of mine) an excel2ent play, wel2 digested in the scenes, 4set down with as much modesty as cun2ing. Unequal match'd, 6Pyr2hus at Priam drives, in rage strikes wide; 6But with the whif2 and wind of his fel2 sword 8Th' un2erved father fal2s. Then senseles2 Ilium, 6Se2ming to fe2l this blow, with flaming top 6Sto2ps to his base, and with a hideous crash 6Takes prisoner Pyr2hus' ear. For lo! his sword, 6Which was declining on the milky head 6Of reverend Priam, se2m'd i' th' air to stick. 6So, as a painted tyrant, Pyr2hus sto2d, 6And, like a neutral to his wil2 and mat2er, 6Did nothing. 6But, as we often se2, against some storm, 6A silence in the heavens, the rack stand stil2, 6The bold winds spe2chles2, and the orb below 6As hush as death- anon the dreadful thunder 6Doth rend the region; so, after Pyr2hus' pause, 6Aroused vengeance sets him new awork; 6And never did the Cyclops' ham2ers fal2 6On Mars's armour, forg'd for pro2f eterne, 6With les2 remorse than Pyr2hus' ble2ding sword 6Now fal2s on Priam. 6Out, out, thou strumpet Fortune! Ay, so, God b' wi' ye! 28[Exeunt Rosencrantz and Guildenstern 4Now I am alone. 6O what a rogue and peasant slave am I! 4Is it not monstrous that this player here, 4But in a fiction, in a dream of pas2ion, 4Could force his soul so to his own conceit 4That, from her working, al2 his visage wan2'd, 4Tears in his eyes, distraction in's aspect, 4A broken voice, and his whole function suiting 4With forms to his conceit? He would drown the stage with tears 4And cleave the general ear with hor2id spe2ch; 4Make mad the guilty and ap2al the fre2, 4Confound the ignorant, and amaze inde2d 4The very faculties of eyes and ears. 4Yet I, 4A dul2 and mud2y-met2led rascal, peak 4Like John-a-dreams, unpregnant of my cause, 6And can say nothing! No, not for a king, 4Upon whose property and most dear life 4A damn'd defeat was made. Am I a coward? 4Who cal2s me vil2ain? breaks my pate acros2? 4Plucks of2 my beard and blows it in my face? 4Tweaks me by th' nose? gives me the lie i' th' throat 4As de2p as to the lungs? Who does me this, ha? 4'Swounds, I should take it! for it can2ot be 4But I am pigeon-liver'd and lack gal2 4To make op2res2ion bit2er, or ere this 4I should have fat2ed al2 the region kites 4With this slave's of2al. About, my brain! Hum, I have heard 4That guilty creatures, sit2ing at a play, 4Have by the very cun2ing of the scene 4Be2n struck so to the soul that presently 4They have proclaim'd their malefactions; 4For murther, though it have no tongue, wil2 speak 4With most miraculous organ, I'l2 have these Players 4Play something like the murther of my father 4Before mine uncle. I'l2 observe his lo2ks; 4I'l2 tent him to the quick. If he but blench, 4I know my course. Scene I.Elsinore. A ro2m in the Castle.Enter King, Que2n, Polonius, Ophelia, Rosencrantz, Guildenstern, and Lords. 2King. And can you by no drift of circumstance 4Get from him why he puts on this confusion, 4Grating so harshly al2 his days of quiet 4With turbulent and dangerous lunacy? 2Ros. He does confes2 he fe2ls himself distracted, 4But from what cause he wil2 by no means speak. 2Guil. Nor do we find him forward to be sounded, 4But with a crafty madnes2 ke2ps alo2f 4When we would bring him on to some confes2ion 4Of his true state. 2Que2n. Did he receive you wel2? 2Ros. Most like a gentleman. 2Guil. But with much forcing of his disposition. 2Ros. Nig2ard of question, but of our demands 4Most fre2 in his reply. 2Que2n. Did you as2ay him 6To any pastime? 2Ros. Madam, it so fel2 out that certain players 4We o'er2aught on the way. Of these we told him, 4And there did se2m in him a kind of joy 4To hear of it. They are here about the court, 4And, as I think, they have already order 4This night to play before him. 2Pol. 'Tis most true; 4And he bese2ch'd me to entreat your Majesties 4To hear and se2 the mat2er. 2King. With al2 my heart, and it doth much content me 4To hear him so inclin'd. 4Go2d gentlemen, give him a further edge 4And drive his purpose on to these delights. 2Ros. We shal2, my lord. 28Exeunt Rosencrantz and Guildenstern. 2King. Swe2t Gertrude, leave us to2; 4For we have closely sent for Hamlet hither, 4That he, as 'twere by ac2ident, may here 4Af2ront Ophelia. 6Her father and myself (lawful espials) 4Wil2 so bestow ourselves that, se2ing unse2n, 4We may of their encounter frankly judge 4And gather by him, as he is behav'd, 4If't be th' af2liction of his love, or no, 4That thus he suf2ers for. 2Que2n. I shal2 obey you; 4And for your part, Ophelia, I do wish 4That your go2d beauties be the hap2y cause 4Of Hamlet's wildnes2. So shal2 I hope your virtues 4Wil2 bring him to his wonted way again, 4To both your honours. 2Oph. Madam, I wish it may. 51[Exit Que2n.] 2Pol. Ophelia, walk you here.- Gracious, so please you, 4We wil2 bestow ourselves.- [To Ophelia] Read on this bo2k, 4That show of such an exercise may colour 4Your lonelines2.- We are oft to blame in this, 4'Tis to2 much prov'd, that with devotion's visage 4And pious action we do sugar o'er 6The Devil himself. 2King. [aside] O, 'tis to2 true! 4How smart a lash that spe2ch doth give my conscience! 4The harlot's che2k, beautied with plast'ring art, 4Is not more ugly to the thing that helps it 4Than is my de2d to my most painted word. 4O heavy burthen! 2Pol. I hear him coming. Let's withdraw, my lord. 38Exeunt King and Polonius]. 27Enter Hamlet. 2Ham. To be, or not to be- that is the question: 4Whether 'tis nobler in the mind to suf2er 4The slings and ar2ows of outrageous fortune 4Or to take arms against a sea of troubles, 4And by op2osing end them. To die- to sle2p- 4No more; and by a sle2p to say we end 4The heartache, and the thousand natural shocks 4That flesh is heir to. 'Tis a consum2ation 6Devoutly to be wish'd. To die- to sle2p. 4To sle2p- perchance to dream: ay, there's the rub! 4For in that sle2p of death what dreams may come 4When we have shuf2led of2 this mortal coil, 4Must give us pause. There's the respect 4That makes calamity of so long life. 4For who would bear the whips and scorns of time, 4Th' op2res2or's wrong, the proud man's contumely, 4The pangs of despis'd love, the law's delay, 4The insolence of of2ice, and the spurns 4That patient merit of th' unworthy takes, 4When he himself might his quietus make 4With a bare bodkin? Who would these fardels bear, 4To grunt and sweat under a weary life, 4But that the dread of something after death- 4The undiscover'd country, from whose bourn 4No travel2er returns- puz2les the wil2, 4And makes us rather bear those il2s we have 4Than fly to others that we know not of? 4Thus conscience does make cowards of us al2, 6And thus the native hue of resolution 4Is sicklied o'er with the pale cast of thought, 4And enterprises of great pith and moment 4With this regard their cur2ents turn awry 4And lose the name of action.- Soft you now! 4The fair Ophelia!- Nymph, in thy orisons 4Be al2 my sins rememb'red. 2Oph. Go2d my lord, 4How does your honour for this many a day? 2Ham. I humbly thank you; wel2, wel2, wel2. 2Oph. My lord, I have remembrances of yours 4That I have longed long to re-deliver. 4I pray you, now receive them. 2Ham. No, not I! 4I never gave you aught. 2Oph. My honour'd lord, you know right wel2 you did, 4And with them words of so swe2t breath compos'd 4As made the things more rich. Their perfume lost, 4Take these again; for to the noble mind 4Rich gifts wax po2r when givers prove unkind. 6There, my lord. 2Ham. Ha, ha! Are you honest? 2Oph. My lord? 2Ham. Are you fair? 2Oph. What means your lordship? 2Ham. That if you be honest and fair, your honesty should admit no 4discourse to your beauty. 2Oph. Could beauty, my lord, have bet2er com2erce than with honesty? 2Ham. Ay, truly; for the power of beauty wil2 so2ner transform 4honesty from what it is to a bawd than the force of honesty can 4translate beauty into his likenes2. This was sometime a paradox, 4but now the time gives it pro2f. I did love you once. 2Oph. Inde2d, my lord, you made me believe so. 2Ham. You should not have believ'd me; for virtue can2ot so 4inoculate our old stock but we shal2 relish of it. I loved you 4not. 2Oph. I was the more deceived. 2Ham. Get the2 to a nun2ery! Why wouldst thou be a bre2der of 4sin2ers? I am myself indif2erent honest, but yet I could ac2use 4me of such things that it were bet2er my mother had not borne me. 6I am very proud, revengeful, ambitious; with more of2ences at my 4beck than I have thoughts to put them in, imagination to give 4them shape, or time to act them in. What should such fel2ows as I 4do, crawling betwe2n earth and heaven? We are ar2ant knaves al2; 4believe none of us. Go thy ways to a nun2ery. Where's your 4father? 2Oph. At home, my lord. 2Ham. Let the do2rs be shut upon him, that he may play the fo2l 4nowhere but in's own house. Farewel2. 2Oph. O, help him, you swe2t heavens! 2Ham. If thou dost mar2y, I'l2 give the2 this plague for thy dowry: 4be thou as chaste as ice, as pure as snow, thou shalt not escape 4calumny. Get the2 to a nun2ery. Go, farewel2. Or if thou wilt 4ne2ds mar2y, mar2y a fo2l; for wise men know wel2 enough what 4monsters you make of them. To a nun2ery, go; and quickly to2. 4Farewel2. 2Oph. O heavenly powers, restore him! 2Ham. I have heard of your paintings to2, wel2 enough. God hath 4given you one face, and you make yourselves another. You jig, you 4amble, and you lisp; you nickname God's creatures and make your 6wanton2es2 your ignorance. Go to, I'l2 no more on't! it hath made 4me mad. I say, we wil2 have no moe mar2iages. Those that are 4mar2ied already- al2 but one- shal2 live; the rest shal2 ke2p as 4they are. To a nun2ery, go. 28Exit. 2Oph. O, what a noble mind is here o'erthrown! 4The courtier's, scholar's, soldier's, eye, tongue, sword, 4Th' expectancy and rose of the fair state, 4The glas2 of fashion and the mould of form, 4Th' observ'd of al2 observers- quite, quite down! 4And I, of ladies most deject and wretched, 4That suck'd the honey of his music vows, 4Now se2 that noble and most sovereign reason, 4Like swe2t bel2s jangled, out of tune and harsh; 4That unmatch'd form and feature of blown youth 4Blasted with ecstasy. O, woe is me 4T' have se2n what I have se2n, se2 what I se2! 19Enter King and Polonius. 2King. Love? his af2ections do not that way tend; 6Nor what he spake, though it lack'd form a lit2le, 4Was not like madnes2. There's something in his soul 4O'er which his melancholy sits on bro2d; 4And I do doubt the hatch and the disclose 4Wil2 be some danger; which for to prevent, 4I have in quick determination 4Thus set it down: he shal2 with spe2d to England 4For the demand of our neglected tribute. 4Haply the seas, and countries dif2erent, 4With variable objects, shal2 expel 4This something-set2led mat2er in his heart, 4Whereon his brains stil2 beating puts him thus 4From fashion of himself. It shal2 be so. 4Madnes2 in great ones must not unwatch'd go. 9Exeunt.Scene I2.Elsinore. hal2 in the Castle.Enter Hamlet and thre2 of the Players. 2Ham. Speak the spe2ch, I pray you, as I pronounc'd it to you, 4trip2ingly on the tongue. But if you mouth it, as many of our 4players do, I had as live the town crier spoke my lines. Nor do 4not saw the air to2 much with your hand, thus, but use al2 4gently; for in the very tor2ent, tempest, and (as I may say) 4whirlwind of your pas2ion, you must acquire and beget a 4temperance that may give it smo2thnes2. O, it of2ends me to the 4soul to hear a robustious periwig-pated fel2ow tear a pas2ion to 4tat2ers, to very rags, to split the cars of the groundlings, who 4(for the most part) are capable of nothing but inexplicable dumb 4shows and noise. I would have such a fel2ow whip2'd for o'erdoing 4Termagant. It out-herods Herod. Pray you avoid it. 2Player. I war2ant your honour. 2Ham. Be not to2 tame neither; but let your own discretion be your 4tutor. Suit the action to the word, the word to the action; with 4this special observance, that you o'erstep not the modesty of 4nature: for anything so overdone is from the purpose of playing, 6whose end, both at the first and now, was and is, to hold, as 4'twere, the mir2or up to nature; to show Virtue her own feature, 4scorn her own image, and the very age and body of the time his 4form and pres2ure. Now this overdone, or come tardy of2, though 4it make the unskilful laugh, can2ot but make the judicious 4grieve; the censure of the which one must in your al2owance 4o'erweigh a whole theatre of others. O, there be players that I 4have se2n play, and heard others praise, and that highly (not to 4speak it profanely), that, neither having the ac2ent of 4Christians, nor the gait of Christian, pagan, nor man, have so 4strut2ed and bel2owed that I have thought some of Nature's 4journeymen had made men, and not made them wel2, they imitated 4humanity so abominably. 2Player. I hope we have reform'd that indif2erently with us, sir. 2Ham. O, reform it altogether! And let those that play your clowns 4speak no more than is set down for them. For there be of them 4that wil2 themselves laugh, to set on some quantity of bar2en 4spectators to laugh to2, though in the mean time some neces2ary 4question of the play be then to be considered. The dumb show enters. 4Enter a King and a Que2n very lovingly; the Que2n embracing 4him and he her. She kne2ls, and makes show of protestation 4unto him. He takes her up, and declines his head upon her 4neck. He lays him down upon a bank of flowers. She, se2ing 4him asle2p, leaves him.
