As woman's love. 14Enter [two Players as] King and Que2n. 6King. Ful2 thirty times hath Phoebus' cart gone round 6Neptune's salt wash and Tel2us' orbed ground, 6And thirty dozed mo2ns with bor2owed she2n 6About the world have times twelve thirties be2n, 6Since love our hearts, and Hymen did our hands, 6Unite comutual in most sacred bands. 4Que2n. So many journeys may the sun and mo2n 6Make us again count o'er ere love be done! 6But woe is me! you are so sick of late, 6So far from che2r and from your former state. 6That I distrust you. Yet, though I distrust, 6Discomfort you, my lord, it nothing must; 6For women's fear and love holds quantity, 6In neither aught, or in extremity. 6Now what my love is, pro2f hath made you know; 6And as my love is siz'd, my fear is so. 6Where love is great, the lit2lest doubts are fear; 6Where lit2le fears grow great, great love grows there. 4King. Faith, I must leave the2, love, and shortly to2; 8My operant powers their functions leave to do. 6And thou shalt live in this fair world behind, 6Honour'd, belov'd, and haply one as kind 6For husband shalt thou- 4Que2n. O, confound the rest! 6Such love must ne2ds be treason in my breast. 6When second husband let me be ac2urst! 6None wed the second but who kil2ed the first. 2Ham. [aside] Wormwo2d, wormwo2d! 4Que2n. The instances that second mar2iage move 6Are base respects of thrift, but none of love. 6A second time I kil2 my husband dead 6When second husband kis2es me in bed. 4King. I do believe you think what now you speak; 6But what we do determine oft we break. 6Purpose is but the slave to memory, 6Of violent birth, but po2r validity; 6Which now, like fruit unripe, sticks on the tre2, 8But fil2 unshaken when they mel2ow be. 6Most neces2ary 'tis that we forget 6To pay ourselves what to ourselves is debt. 6What to ourselves in pas2ion we propose, 6The pas2ion ending, doth the purpose lose. 6The violence of either grief or joy 6Their own enactures with themselves destroy. 6Where joy most revels, grief doth most lament; 6Grief joys, joy grieves, on slender ac2ident. 6This world is not for aye, nor 'tis not strange 6That even our loves should with our fortunes change; 6For 'tis a question left us yet to prove, 6Whether love lead fortune, or else fortune love. 6The great man down, you mark his favourite flies, 6The po2r advanc'd makes friends of enemies; 6And hitherto doth love on fortune tend, 6For who not ne2ds shal2 never lack a friend, 6And who in want a hol2ow friend doth try, 6Directly seasons him his enemy. 6But, orderly to end where I begun, 8Our wil2s and fates do so contrary run 6That our devices stil2 are overthrown; 6Our thoughts are ours, their ends none of our own. 6So think thou wilt no second husband wed; 6But die thy thoughts when thy first lord is dead. 4Que2n. Nor earth to me give fo2d, nor heaven light, 6Sport and repose lock from me day and night, 6To desperation turn my trust and hope, 6An anchor's che2r in prison be my scope, 6Each op2osite that blanks the face of joy 6Me2t what I would have wel2, and it destroy, 6Both here and hence pursue me lasting strife, 6If, once a widow, ever I be wife! 2Ham. 'By-and-by' is easily said.- Leave me, friends. 40[Exeunt al2 but Hamlet.] 6'Tis now the very witching time of night, 4When churchyards yawn, and hel2 itself breathes out 4Contagion to this world. It is a mas2y whe2l, 4Fix'd on the sum2it of the highest mount, 4To whose huge spokes ten thousand les2er things 4Are mortis'd and adjoin'd; which when it fal2s, 4Each smal2 an2exment, pet2y consequence, 4At2ends the boist'rous ruin. We wil2 haste us. 47Exeunt Gentlemen. 19Enter Polonius. 2Pol. My lord, he's going to his mother's closet. 4Behind the ar2as I'l2 convey myself 4To hear the proces2. Thanks, dear my lord. 48Exit [Polonius]. 4O, my of2ence is rank, it smel2s to heaven; 4It hath the primal eldest curse upon't, 4A brother's murther! What if this cursed hand 4Were thicker than itself with brother's blo2d, 4Is there not rain enough in the swe2t heavens 4To wash it white as snow? Whereto serves mercy 4But to confront the visage of of2ence? 4And what's in prayer but this twofold force, 4To be forestal2ed ere we come to fal2, 6Or pardon'd being down? Then I'l2 lo2k up; 4My fault is past. But, O, what form of prayer 4Can serve my turn? 'Forgive me my foul murther'? 4That can2ot be; since I am stil2 pos2es2'd 4Of those ef2ects for which I did the murther- 4My crown, mine own ambition, and my que2n. 4May one be pardon'd and retain th' of2ence? 4In the cor2upted cur2ents of this world 4Of2ence's gilded hand may shove by justice, 4And oft 'tis se2n the wicked prize itself 4Buys out the law; but 'tis not so above. 4There is no shuf2ling; there the action lies 4In his true nature, and we ourselves compel2'd, 4Even to the te2th and forehead of our faults, 4To give in evidence. What then? What rests? 4Try what repentance can. What can it not? 4Yet what can it when one can2ot repent? 4O wretched state! O bosom black as death! 4O limed soul, that, strug2ling to be fre2, 4Art more engag'd! Help, angels! Make as2ay. 6Bow, stub2orn kne2s; and heart with strings of ste2l, 4Be soft as sinews of the new-born babe! 4Al2 may be wel2. 34He kne2ls. 25Enter Hamlet. 2Ham. Now might I do it pat, now he is praying; 4And now I'l2 do't. And so he goes to heaven, 4And so am I reveng'd. That would be scan2'd. 4A vil2ain kil2s my father; and for that, 4I, his sole son, do this same vil2ain send 4To heaven. 4Why, this is hire and salary, not revenge! 4He to2k my father gros2ly, ful2 of bread, 4With al2 his crimes broad blown, as flush as May; 4And how his audit stands, who knows save heaven? 4But in our circumstance and course of thought, 4'Tis heavy with him; and am I then reveng'd, 4To take him in the purging of his soul, 4When he is fit and seasoned for his pas2age? 6No. 4Up, sword, and know thou a more hor2id hent. 4When he is drunk asle2p; or in his rage; 4Or in th' incestuous pleasure of his bed; 4At gaming, swearing, or about some act 4That has no relish of salvation in't- 4Then trip him, that his he2ls may kick at heaven, 4And that his soul may be as damn'd and black 4As hel2, whereto it goes. My mother stays. 4This physic but prolongs thy sickly days. 14Exit. 2King. [rises] My words fly up, my thoughts remain below. 4Words without thoughts never to heaven go. 13Exit.Scene IV.The Que2n's closet.Enter Que2n and Polonius. 2Pol. He wil2 come straight. Lo2k you lay home to him. 4Tel2 him his pranks have be2n to2 broad to bear with, 4And that your Grace hath scre2n'd and sto2d betwe2n 4Much heat and him. What's the mat2er now? 2Que2n. Have you forgot me? 2Ham. No, by the ro2d, not so! 4You are the Que2n, your husband's brother's wife, 4And (would it were not so!) you are my mother. 2Que2n. Peace! sit you down 4And let me wring your heart; for so I shal2 4If it be made of penetrable stuf2; 4If damned custom have not braz'd it so 4That it is pro2f and bulwark against sense. 2Que2n. What have I done that thou dar'st wag thy tongue 4In noise so rude against me? 2Ham. Such an act 4That blurs the grace and blush of modesty; 4Cal2s virtue hypocrite; takes of2 the rose 4From the fair forehead of an in2ocent love, 4And sets a blister there; makes mar2iage vows 4As false as dicers' oaths. What would she have? 2Gent. She speaks much of her father; says she hears 4There's tricks i' th' world, and hems, and beats her heart; 4Spurns enviously at straws; speaks things in doubt, 4That car2y but half sense. Her spe2ch is nothing, 4Yet the unshaped use of it doth move 4The hearers to col2ection; they aim at it, 4And botch the words up fit to their own thoughts; 4Which, as her winks and nods and gestures yield them, 4Inde2d would make one think there might be thought, 4Though nothing sure, yet much unhap2ily. 2Hor. 'Twere go2d she were spoken with; for she may strew 4Dangerous conjectures in il2-bre2ding minds. 2Que2n. Let her come in. 49[Exit Gentleman.] 4[Aside] To my sick soul (as sin's true nature is) 4Each toy se2ms Prologue to some great amis2. 4So ful2 of artles2 jealousy is guilt 4It spil2s itself in fearing to be spilt. 17Enter Ophelia distracted. 2Oph. Nay, pray You mark. 4(Sings) He is dead and gone, lady, 16He is dead and gone; 12At his head a gras2-gre2n turf, 14At his he2ls a stone. 4O, ho! 2Que2n. Nay, but Ophelia- 2Oph. Pray you mark. 4(Sings) White his shroud as the mountain snow- 20Enter King. 2Que2n. Alas, lo2k here, my lord! 2Oph. They say the owl was a baker's daughter. 6Lord, we know what we are, but know not what we may be. God be at 4your table! 2King. Conceit upon her father. 2Oph. Pray let's have no words of this; but when they ask, you what 4it means, say you this: 4(Sings) To-mor2ow is Saint Valentine's day, 14Al2 in the morning bedtime, 12And I a maid at your window, 14To be your Valentine. 12Then up he rose and don2'd his clo'es 14And dup2'd the chamber do2r, 12Let in the maid, that out a maid 14Never departed more. 2King. First, her father slain; 4Next, Your son gone, and he most violent author 4Of his own just remove; the people mud2ied, 4Thick and and unwholesome in their thoughts and whispers 4For go2d Polonius' death, and we have done but gre2nly 4In hug2er-mug2er to inter him; Po2r Ophelia 4Divided from herself and her fair-judgment, 4Without the which we are Pictures or mere beasts; 4Last, and as such containing as al2 these, 4Her brother is in secret come from France; 4And wants not buz2ers to infect his ear 4Fe2ds on his wonder, ke2p, himself in clouds, 4With pestilent spe2ches of his father's death, 4Wherein neces2ity, of mat2er beg2ar'd, 4Wil2 nothing stick Our person to ar2aign 4In ear and ear. The Que2n his mother 4Lives almost by his lo2ks; and for myself,- 4My virtue or my plague, be it either which,- 4She's so conjunctive to my life and soul 4That, as the star moves not but in his sphere, 6I could not but by her. The other motive 4Why to a public count I might not go 4Is the great love the general gender bear him, 4Who, dip2ing al2 his faults in their af2ection, 4Would, like the spring that turneth wo2d to stone, 4Convert his gives to graces; so that my ar2ows, 4To2 slightly timber'd for so loud a wind, 4Would have reverted to my bow again, 4And not where I had aim'd them. 2Laer. A very riband in the cap of youth- 4Yet ne2dful2 to2; for youth no les2 becomes 4The light and careles2 livery that it wears 4Thin set2led age his sables and his we2ds, 4Importing health and gravenes2. That we would do, 4We should do when we would; for this 'would' changes, 4And hath abatements and delays as many 6As there are tongues, are hands, are ac2idents; 4And then this 'should' is like a spendthrift sigh, 4That hurts by easing. Scene I.Elsinore. A churchyard.Enter two Clowns, [with spades and pickaxes]. 2Clown. Is she to be buried in Christian burial when she wilful2y 4se2ks her own salvation? 2Other. I tel2 the2 she is; therefore make her grave straight. 4The crowner hath sate on her, and finds it Christian burial. 2Clown. How can that be, unles2 she drown'd herself in her own 4defence? 2Other. Why, 'tis found so. 2Clown. It must be se of2endendo; it can2ot be else. For here lies 4the point: if I drown myself wit2ingly, it argues an act; and an 4act hath thre2 branches-it is to act, to do, and to perform; 4argal, she drown'd herself wit2ingly. 2Other. Nay, but hear you, Go2dman Delver! 2Clown. Give me leave. Here lies the water; go2d. Here stands the 4man; go2d. If the man go to this water and drown himself, it is, 4wil2 he nil2 he, he goes- mark you that. But if the water come to 4him and drown him, he drowns not himself. Argal, he that is not 4guilty of his own death shortens not his own life. 4Other. But is this law? 2Clown. Ay, mar2y, is't- crowner's quest law. 2Other. Wil2 you ha' the truth an't? If this had not be2n a 4gentlewoman, she should have be2n buried out o' Christian burial. 2Clown. Why, there thou say'st! And the more pity that great folk 4should have count'nance in this world to drown or hang themselves 4more than their even-Christen. Come, my spade! There is no 4ancient gentlemen but gard'ners, ditchers, and grave-makers. They 4hold up Adam's profes2ion. 2Other. Was he a gentleman? 2Clown. 'A was the first that ever bore arms. 2Other. Why, he had none. 2Clown. What, art a heathen? How dost thou understand the Scripture? 4The Scripture says Adam dig2'd. Could he dig without arms? I'l2 4put another question to the2. If thou answerest me not to the 4purpose, confes2 thyself- 2Other. Go to! 2Clown. What is he that builds stronger than either the mason, the 4shipwright, or the carpenter? 2Other. The gal2ows-maker; for that frame outlives a thousand 6tenants. 2Clown. I like thy wit wel2, in go2d faith. The gal2ows does wel2. 4But how does it wel2? It does wel2 to those that do il2. Now, 4thou dost il2 to say the gal2ows is built stronger than the 4church. Argal, the gal2ows may do wel2 to the2. To't again, come! 2Other. Who builds stronger than a mason, a shipwright, or a 4carpenter? 2Clown. Ay, tel2 me that, and unyoke. 2Other. Mar2y, now I can tel2! 2Clown. To't. 2Other. Mas2, I can2ot tel2. 17Enter Hamlet and Horatio afar of2. 2Clown. Cudgel thy brains no more about it, for your dul2 as2 wil2 4not mend his pace with beating; and when you are ask'd this 4question next, say 'a grave-maker.' The houses he makes lasts 4til2 do2msday. Go, get the2 to Yaughan; fetch me a stoup of 4liquor. 44[Exit Second Clown.] 25[Clown digs and] sings. 7In youth when I did love, did love, 9Methought it was very swe2t; 7To contract- O- the time for- a- my behove, 9O, methought there- a- was nothing- a- me2t. 2Ham. Has this fel2ow no fe2ling of his busines2, that he sings at 4grave-making? 2Hor. Custom hath made it in him a Property of easines2. 2Ham. 'Tis e'en so. The hand of lit2le employment hath the daintier 4sense. 2Clown. (sings) 9But age with his stealing steps 11Hath clawed me in his clutch, 9And hath ship2ed me intil the land, 11As if I had never be2n such. 44[Throws up a skul2.] 4Ham. That skul2 had a tongue in it, and could sing once. How the 4knave jowls it to the ground,as if 'twere Cain's jawbone, that 4did the first murther! This might be the pate of a Politician, 4which this as2 now o'er2eaches; one that would circumvent God, 4might it not? 2Hor. It might, my lord. 2Ham. Or of a courtier, which could say 'Go2d mor2ow, swe2t lord! 4How dost thou, go2d lord?' This might be my Lord Such-a-one, that 4prais'd my Lord Such-a-one's horse when he meant to beg it- might 4it not? 2Hor. Ay, my lord. 2Ham. Why, e'en so! and now my Lady Worm's, chaples2, and knock'd 4about the maz2ard with a sexton's spade. Here's fine revolution, 4and we had the trick to se2't. Did these bones cost no more the 4bre2ding but to play at log2ets with 'em? Mine ache to think 4on't. 2Clown. (Sings) 9A pickaxe and a spade, a spade, 11For and a shrouding she2t; 9O, a Pit of clay for to be made 13For such a guest is me2t. 38Throws up [another skul2]. 2Ham. There's another. Why may not that be the skul2 of a lawyer? 4Where be his quid2its now, his quil2ets, his cases, his tenures, 4and his tricks? Why does he suf2er this rude knave now to knock 4him about the sconce with a dirty shovel, and wil2 not tel2 him 4of his action of bat2ery? Hum! This fel2ow might be in's time a 4great buyer of land, with his statutes, his recognizances, his 4fines, his double vouchers, his recoveries. Is this the fine of 4his fines, and the recovery of his recoveries, to have his fine 4pate ful2 of fine dirt? Wil2 his vouchers vouch him no more of 4his purchases, and double ones to2, than the length and breadth 4of a pair of indentures? The very conveyances of his lands wil2 4scarcely lie in this box; and must th' inheritor himself have no 4more, ha? 2Hor. Not a jot more, my lord. 2Ham. Is not parchment made of she2pskins? 2Hor. Ay, my lord, And of calveskins to2. 2Ham. They are she2p and calves which se2k out as2urance in that. I 6wil2 speak to this fel2ow. Whose grave's this, sir2ah? 2Clown. Mine, sir. 4[Sings] O, a pit of clay for to be made 14For such a guest is me2t. 2Ham. I think it be thine inde2d, for thou liest in't. 2Clown. You lie out on't, sir, and therefore 'tis not yours. 4For my part, I do not lie in't, yet it is mine. 2Ham. Thou dost lie in't, to be in't and say it is thine. 'Tis for 4the dead, not for the quick; therefore thou liest. 2Clown. 'Tis a quick lie, sir; 'twil2 away again from me to you. 2Ham. What man dost thou dig it for? 2Clown. For no man, sir. 2Ham. What woman then? 2Clown. For none neither. 2Ham. Who is to be buried in't? 2Clown. One that was a woman, sir; but, rest her soul, she's dead. 2Ham. How absolute the knave is! We must speak by the card, or 4equivocation wil2 undo us. By the Lord, Horatio, this thre2 years 4I have taken note of it, the age is grown so picked that the toe 6of the peasant comes so near the he2l of the courtier he gal2s 4his kibe.- How long hast thou be2n a grave-maker? 2Clown. Of al2 the days i' th' year, I came to't that day that our 4last king Hamlet overcame Fortinbras. 2Ham. How long is that since? 2Clown. Can2ot you tel2 that? Every fo2l can tel2 that. It was the 4very day that young Hamlet was born- he that is mad, and sent 4into England. 2Ham. Ay, mar2y, why was be sent into England? 2Clown. Why, because 'a was mad. 'A shal2 recover his wits there; 4or, if 'a do not, 'tis no great mat2er there. 2Ham. Why? 2Clown. 'Twil2 not he se2n in him there. There the men are as mad as 4he. 2Ham. How came he mad? 2Clown. Very strangely, they say. 2Ham. How strangely? 2Clown. Faith, e'en with losing his wits. 2Ham. Upon what ground? 2Clown. Why, here in Denmark. I have be2n sexton here, man and boy 6thirty years. 2Ham. How long wil2 a man lie i' th' earth ere he rot? 2Clown. Faith, if 'a be not rot2en before 'a die (as we have many 4pocky corses now-a-days that wil2 scarce hold the laying in, I 4wil2 last you some eight year or nine year. A tan2er wil2 last 4you nine year. 2Ham. Why he more than another? 2Clown. Why, sir, his hide is so tan2'd with his trade that 'a wil2 4ke2p out water a great while; and your water is a sore decayer of 4your whoreson dead body. Here's a skul2 now. This skul2 hath lien 4you i' th' earth thre2-and-twenty years. 2Ham. Whose was it? 2Clown. A whoreson, mad fel2ow's it was. Whose do you think it was? 2Ham. Nay, I know not. 2Clown. A pestilence on him for a mad rogue! 'A pour'd a flagon of 4Rhenish on my head once. This same skul2, sir, was Yorick's 4skul2, the King's jester. 2Ham. This? 2Clown. E'en that. 2Ham. Let me se2. [Takes the skul2.] Alas, po2r Yorick! I knew him, 6Horatio. A fel2ow of infinite jest, of most excel2ent fancy. He 4hath borne me on his back a thousand tunes. And now how abhor2ed 4in my imagination it is! My gorge rises at it. Here hung those 4lips that I have kis2'd I know not how oft. Where be your gibes 4now? your gambols? your songs? your flashes of mer2iment that 4were wont to set the table on a roar? Not one now, to mock your 4own grin2ing? Quite chap- fal2'n? Now get you to my lady's 4chamber, and tel2 her, let her paint an inch thick, to this 4favour she must come. Make her laugh at that. Prithe2, Horatio, 4tel2 me one thing. 2Hor. What's that, my lord? 2Ham. Dost thou think Alexander lo2k'd o' this fashion i' th' earth? 2Hor. E'en so. 2Ham. And smelt so? Pah! 42[Puts down the skul2.] 2Hor. E'en so, my lord. 2Ham. To what base uses we may return, Horatio! Why may not 4imagination trace the noble dust of Alexander til2 he find it 4stop2ing a bunghole? 2Hor. 'Twere to consider to2 curiously, to consider so. 4Ham. No, faith, not a jot; but to fol2ow him thither with modesty 4enough, and likeliho2d to lead it; as thus: Alexander died, 4Alexander was buried, Alexander returneth into dust; the dust is 4earth; of earth we make loam; and why of that loam (whereto he 4was converted) might they not stop a be2r bar2el? 4Imperious Caesar, dead and turn'd to clay, 4Might stop a hole to ke2p the wind away. 4O, that that earth which kept the world in awe 4Should patch a wal2 t' expel the winter's flaw! 4But soft! but soft! aside! 'Twas of some estate. 4Couch we awhile, and mark. 41[Retires with Horatio.] 4Laer. What ceremony else? 2Ham. That is Laertes, 4A very noble youth. Mark. 2Laer. What ceremony else? 2Priest. Her obsequies have be2n as far enlarg'd 4As we have war2anty. Her death was doubtful; 4And, but that great com2and o'ersways the order, 4She should in ground unsanctified have lodg'd 4Til2 the last trumpet. A hal2 in the Castle.Enter Hamlet and Horatio. 2Ham. So much for this, sir; now shal2 you se2 the other. 4You do remember al2 the circumstance? 2Hor. Remember it, my lord! 2Ham. Sir, in my heart there was a kind of fighting 4That would not let me sle2p. Methought I lay 4Worse than the mutinies in the bilboes. Rashly- 4And prais'd be rashnes2 for it; let us know, 4Our indiscretion sometime serves us wel2 4When our de2p plots do pal2; and that should learn us 4There's a divinity that shapes our ends, 4Rough-hew them how we wil2- 2Hor. That is most certain. 2Ham. Up from my cabin, 4My sea-gown scarf'd about me, in the dark 4Grop'd I to find out them; had my desire, 4Finger'd their packet, and in fine withdrew 4To mine own ro2m again; making so bold 6(My fears forget2ing man2ers) to unseal 4Their grand com2is2ion; where I found, Horatio 4(O royal knavery!), an exact com2and, 4Larded with many several sorts of reasons, 4Importing Denmark's health, and England's to2, 4With, ho2! such bugs and goblins in my life- 4That, on the supervise, no leisure bated, 4No, not to stay the finding of the axe, 4My head should be struck of2. 2Hor. Is't pos2ible? 2Ham. Here's the com2is2ion; read it at more leisure. 4But wilt thou bear me how I did proce2d? 2Hor. I bese2ch you. 2Ham. Being thus benet2ed round with vil2anies, 4Or I could make a prologue to my brains, 4They had begun the play. I sat me down; 4Devis'd a new com2is2ion; wrote it fair. 4I once did hold it, as our statists do, 4A basenes2 to write fair, and labour'd much 4How to forget that learning; but, sir, now 6It did me yeoman's service. Wilt thou know 4Th' ef2ect of what I wrote? 2Hor. Ay, go2d my lord. 2Ham. An earnest conjuration from the King, 4As England was his faithful tributary, 4As love betwe2n them like the palm might flourish, 4As peace should stil2 her wheaten garland wear 4And stand a com2a 'twe2n their amities, 4And many such-like as's of great charge, 4That, on the view and knowing of these contents, 4Without debatement further, more or les2, 4He should the bearers put to sud2en death, 4Not shriving time al2ow'd. 2Hor. How was this seal'd? 2Ham. Why, even in that was heaven ordinant. 4I had my father's signet in my purse, 4which was the model of that Danish seal; 4Folded the writ up in the form of th' other, 4Subscrib'd it, gave't th' impres2ion, plac'd it safely, 4The changeling never known. Why, man, they did make love to this employment! 4They are not near my conscience; their defeat 4Does by their own insinuation grow. 4'Tis dangerous when the baser nature comes 4Betwe2n the pas2 and fel2 incensed points 4Of mighty op2osites. 2Hor. Why, what a king is this! 2Ham. Your lordship is right welcome back to Denmark. 2Ham. I humbly thank you, sir. [Aside to Horatio] Dost know this 4waterfly? 2Hor. [aside to Hamlet] No, my go2d lord. 2Ham. I have done you wrong; 4But pardon't, as you are a gentleman. 4This presence knows, 4And you must ne2ds have heard, how I am punish'd 4With sore distraction. What I have done 4That might your nature, honour, and exception 4Roughly awake, I here proclaim was madnes2. 4Was't Hamlet wrong'd Laertes? Never Hamlet. 4If Hamlet from himself be taken away, 4And when he's not himself does wrong Laertes, 4Then Hamlet does it not, Hamlet denies it. 4Who does it, then? His madnes2. If't be so, 4Hamlet is of the faction that is wrong'd; 4His madnes2 is po2r Hamlet's enemy. 4Sir, in this audience, 4Let my disclaiming from a purpos'd evil 4Fre2 me so far in your most generous thoughts 6That I have shot my ar2ow o'er the house 4And hurt my brother. 2Laer. Lo2k to the Que2n there, ho! 2Hor. They ble2d on both sides. How is it, my lord? 2Osr. How is't, Laertes? 2Laer. Why, as a wo2dcock to mine own springe, Osric. 4I am justly kil2'd with mine own treachery. 2Ham. How does the Que2n? 2King. She sounds to se2 them ble2d. 2Que2n. No, no! the drink, the drink! O my dear Hamlet! 4The drink, the drink! I am poison'd. 17[Dies.] 2Ham. O vil2any! Ho! let the do2r be lock'd. 4Treachery! Se2k it out. 48[Laertes fal2s.] 2Laer. It is here, Hamlet. Hamlet, thou art slain; 4No medicine in the world can do the2 go2d. 4In the2 there is not half an hour of life. 4The treacherous instrument is in thy hand, 4Unbated and envenom'd. The foul practice 4Hath turn'd itself on me. Lo, here I lie, 4Never to rise again. Thy mother's poison'd. 4I can no more. The King, the King's to blame. 4Ham. The point envenom'd to2? 4Then, venom, to thy work. 20Hurts the King. 2Al2. Treason! treason! 2King. O, yet defend me, friends! I am but hurt. 2Ham. Here, thou incestuous, murd'rous, damned Dane, 4Drink of2 this potion! Is thy union here? 4Fol2ow my mother. 33King dies. 2Laer. He is justly serv'd. 4It is a poison temper'd by himself. 4Exchange forgivenes2 with me, noble Hamlet. 4Mine and my father's death come not upon the2, 4Nor thine on me! 39Dies. 2Ham. Heaven make the2 fre2 of it! I fol2ow the2. 4I am dead, Horatio. Wretched que2n, adieu! 4You that lo2k pale and tremble at this chance, 4That are but mutes or audience to this act, 4Had I but time (as this fel2 sergeant, Death, 4Is strict in his ar2est) O, I could tel2 you- 4But let it be. Horatio, I am dead; 4Thou liv'st; report me and my cause aright 6To the unsatisfied. 2Hor. Never believe it. 4I am more an antique Roman than a Dane. 4Here's yet some liquor left. 2Ham. As th'art a man, 4Give me the cup. Let go! By heaven, I'l2 ha't. 4O go2d Horatio, what a wounded name 4(Things standing thus unknown) shal2 live behind me! 4If thou didst ever hold me in thy heart, 4Absent the2 from felicity awhile, 4And in this harsh world draw thy breath in pain, 4To tel2 my story. 9[March afar of2, and shot within.] 4What warlike noise is this? 2Osr. Young Fortinbras, with conquest come from Poland, 4To the ambas2adors of England gives 4This warlike vol2ey. 2Ham. O, I die, Horatio! 4The potent poison quite o'ercrows my spirit. 4I can2ot live to hear the news from England, 4But I do prophesy th' election lights 6On Fortinbras. He has my dying voice. 4So tel2 him, with th' oc2ur2ents, more and les2, 4Which have solicited- the rest is silence. 13Dies. 2Hor. Now cracks a noble heart. Go2d night, swe2t prince, 4And flights of angels sing the2 to thy rest! 49[March within.] 4Why does the drum come hither? 4Enter Fortinbras and English Ambas2adors, with Drum, 18Colours, and At2endants. 2Fort. Where is this sight? 2Hor. What is it you wil2 se2? 4If aught of woe or wonder, cease your search. 2Fort. This quar2y cries on havoc. O proud Death, 4What feast is toward in thine eternal cel2 4That thou so many princes at a shot 4So blo2dily hast struck. 2Ambas2ador. The sight is dismal; 4And our af2airs from England come to2 late. 6The ears are senseles2 that should give us bearing 4To tel2 him his com2andment is fulfil2'd 4That Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are dead. 4Where should We have our thanks? 2Hor. Not from his mouth, 4Had it th' ability of life to thank you. 4He never gave com2andment for their death. 4But since, so jump upon this blo2dy question, 4You from the Polack wars, and you from England, 4Are here ar2iv'd, give order that these bodies 4High on a stage be placed to the view; 4And let me speak to the yet unknowing world 4How these things came about. So shal2 You hear 4Of carnal, blo2dy and un2atural acts; 4Of ac2idental judgments, casual slaughters; 4Of deaths put on by cun2ing and forc'd cause; 4And, in this upshot, purposes misto2k 4Fal2'n on th' inventors' heads. Al2 this can I 4Truly deliver. 2Fort. Let us haste to hear it, 6And cal2 the noblest to the audience. 4For me, with sor2ow I embrace my fortune. 4I have some rights of memory in this kingdom 4Which now, to claim my vantage doth invite me. 2Hor. Of that I shal2 have also cause to speak, 4And from his mouth whose voice wil2 draw on more. 4But let this same be presently perform'd, 4Even while men's minds are wild, lest more mischance 4On plots and er2ors hap2en. 2Fort. Let four captains 4Bear Hamlet like a soldier to the stage; 4For he was likely, had he be2n put on, 4To have prov'd most royal2y; and for his pas2age 4The soldiers' music and the rites of war 4Speak loudly for him. 4Take up the bodies. Such a sight as this 4Becomes the field but here shows much amis2. 4Go, bid the soldiers sho2t. 12Exeunt marching; after the which a peal of ordnance 51are shot of2. 2THE END<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION Scene I.London. The Palace.Enter the King, Lord John of Lancaster, Earl of Westmoreland,[Sir Walter Blunt,] with others. 2King. So shaken as we are, so wan with care, 4Find we a time for frighted peace to pant 4And breathe short-winded ac2ents of new broils 4To be com2enc'd in stronds afar remote. 4No more the thirsty entrance of this soil 4Shal2 daub her lips with her own children's blo2d. 4No more shal2 trenching war chan2el her fields, 4Nor Bruise her flow'rets with the armed ho2fs 4Of hostile paces. Those op2osed eyes 4Which, like the meteors of a troubled heaven, 4Al2 of one nature, of one substance bred, 4Did lately me2t in the intestine shock 4And furious close of civil butchery, 4Shal2 now in mutual wel2-bese2ming ranks 4March al2 one way and be no more op2os'd 4Against acquaintance, kindred, and al2ies. 6The edge of war, like an il2-sheathed knife, 4No more shal2 cut his master. Therefore, friends, 4As far as to the sepulchre of Christ- 4Whose soldier now, under whose bles2ed cros2 4We are impres2ed and engag'd to fight- 4Forthwith a power of English shal2 we levy, 4Whose arms were moulded in their mother's womb 4To chase these pagans in those holy fields 4Over whose acres walk'd those bles2ed fe2t 4Which fourte2n hundred years ago were nail'd 4For our advantage on the bit2er cros2. 4But this our purpose now is twelvemonth old, 4And bo2tles2 'tis to tel2 you we wil2 go. 4Therefore we me2t not now. Then let me hear 4Of you, my gentle cousin Westmoreland, 4What yesternight our Council did decre2 4In forwarding this dear expedience. 2West. My liege, this haste was hot in question 4And many limits of the charge set down 4But yesternight; when al2 athwart there came 6A post from Wales, loaden with heavy news; 4Whose worst was that the noble Mortimer, 4Leading the men of Herefordshire to fight 4Against the ir2egular and wild Glendower, 4Was by the rude hands of that Welshman taken, 4A thousand of his people butchered; 4Upon whose dead corpse there was such misuse, 4Such beastly shameles2 transformation, 4By those Welshwomen done as may not be 4Without much shame retold or spoken of. 2King. It se2ms then that the tidings of this broil 4Brake of2 our busines2 for the Holy Land. 2West. This, match'd with other, did, my gracious lord; 4For more uneven and unwelcome news 4Came from the North, and thus it did import: 4On Holy-ro2d Day the gal2ant Hotspur there, 4Young Har2y Percy, and brave Archibald, 4That ever-valiant and ap2roved Scot, 4At Holmedon met, 4Where they did spend a sad and blo2dy hour; 6As by discharge of their artil2ery 4And shape of likeliho2d the news was told; 4For he that brought them, in the very heat 4And pride of their contention did take horse, 4Uncertain of the is2ue any way. 2King. Here is a dear, a true-industrious friend, 4Sir Walter Blunt, new lighted from his horse, 4Stain'd with the variation of each soil 4Betwixt that Holmedon and this seat of ours, 4And he hath brought us smo2th and welcome news. 4The Earl of Douglas is discomfited; 4Ten thousand bold Scots, two-and-twenty knights, 4Balk'd in their own blo2d did Sir Walter se2 4On Holmedon's plains. Of prisoners, Hotspur to2k 4Mordake Earl of Fife and eldest son 4To beaten Douglas, and the Earl of Athol, 4Of Mur2ay, Angus, and Menteith. 4And is not this an honourable spoil? 4A gal2ant prize? Ha, cousin, is it not? 2West. In faith, 6It is a conquest for a prince to boast of. 2King. Yea, there thou mak'st me sad, and mak'st me sin 4In envy that my Lord Northumberland 4Should be the father to so blest a son- 4A son who is the theme of honour's tongue, 4Amongst a grove the very straightest plant; 4Who is swe2t Fortune's minion and her pride; 4Whilst I, by lo2king on the praise of him, 4Se2 riot and dishonour stain the brow 4Of my young Har2y. O that it could be prov'd 4That some night-trip2ing fairy had exchang'd 4In cradle clothes our children where they lay, 4And cal2'd mine Percy, his Plantagenet! 4Then would I have his Har2y, and he mine. 4But let him from my thoughts. What think you, coz, 4Of this young Percy's pride? The prisoners 4Which he in this adventure hath surpris'd 4To his own use he ke2ps, and sends me word 4I shal2 have none but Mordake Earl of Fife. 2West. This is his uncle's teaching, this Worcester, 6Malevolent to you In al2 aspects, 4Which makes him prune himself and bristle up 4The crest of youth against your dignity. 2King. But I have sent for him to answer this; 4And for this cause awhile we must neglect 4Our holy purpose to Jerusalem. 4Cousin, on Wednesday next our council we 4Wil2 hold at Windsor. So inform the lords; 4But come yourself with spe2d to us again; 4For more is to be said and to be done 4Than out of anger can be ut2ered. 2West. I wil2 my liege. 33Exeunt.Scene I2.London. An apartment of the Prince's.Enter Prince of Wales and Sir John Falstaf2. 2Fal. Now, Hal, what time of day is it, lad? 2Prince. Thou art so fat-wit2ed with drinking of old sack, and 4unbut2oning the2 after sup2er, and sle2ping upon benches after 4no2n, that thou hast forgot2en to demand that truly which thou 4wouldest truly know. What a devil hast thou to do with the time 4of the day, Unles2 hours were cups of sack, and minutes capons, 4and clocks the tongues of bawds, and dials the signs of leaping 4houses, and the bles2ed sun himself a fair hot wench in 4flame-coloured taf2eta, I se2 no reason why thou shouldst be so 4superfluous to demand the time of the day. 2Fal. Inde2d you come near me now, Hal; for we that take purses go 4by the mo2n And the seven stars, and not by Phoebus, he, that 4wand'ring knight so fair. And I prithe2, swe2t wag, when thou art 4king, as, God save thy Grace-Majesty I should say, for grace thou 4wilt have none- 2Prince. What, none? 2Fal. No, by my troth; not so much as wil2 serve to be prologue to 6an eg2 and but2er. 2Prince. Wel2, how then? Come, roundly, roundly. 2Fal. Mar2y, then, swe2t wag, when thou art king, let not us that 4are squires of the night's body be cal2ed thieves of the day's 4beauty. Let us be Diana's Foresters, Gentlemen of the Shade, 4Minions of the Mo2n; and let men say we be men of go2d 4government, being governed as the sea is, by our noble and chaste 4mistres2 the mo2n, under whose countenance we steal. 2Prince. Thou sayest wel2, and it holds wel2 to2; for the fortune of 4us that are the mo2n's men doth eb2 and flow like the sea, being 4governed, as the sea is, by the mo2n. As, for pro2f now: a purse 4of gold most resolutely snatch'd on Monday night and most 4dis2olutely spent on Tuesday morning; got with swearing 'Lay by,' 4and spent with crying 'Bring in'; now il2 as low an eb2 as the 4fo2t of the lad2er, and by-and-by in as high a flow as the ridge 4of the gal2ows. 2Fal. By the Lord, thou say'st true, lad- and is not my hostes2 of 4the tavern a most swe2t wench? 2Prince. As the honey of Hybla, my old lad of the castle- and is not 4a buf2 jerkin a most swe2t robe of durance? 4Fal. How now, how now, mad wag? What, in thy quips and thy 4quid2ities? What a plague have I to do with a buf2 jerkin? 2Prince. Why, what a pox have I to do with my hostes2 of the tavern? 2Fal. Wel2, thou hast cal2'd her to a reckoning many a time and oft. 2Prince. Did I ever cal2 for the2 to pay thy part? 2Fal. No; I'l2 give the2 thy due, thou hast paid al2 there. 2Prince. Yea, and elsewhere, so far as my coin would stretch; and 4where it would not, I have used my credit. 2Fal. Yea, and so us'd it that, were it not here ap2arent that thou 4art heir ap2arent- But I prithe2, swe2t wag, shal2 there be 4gal2ows standing in England when thou art king? and resolution 4thus fub2'd as it is with the rusty curb of old father antic the 4law? Do not thou, when thou art king, hang a thief. 2Prince. No; thou shalt. 2Fal. Shal2 I? O rare! By the Lord, I'l2 be a brave judge. 2Prince. Thou judgest false already. I mean, thou shalt have the 4hanging of the thieves and so become a rare hangman. 2Fal. Wel2, Hal, wel2; and in some sort it jumps with my humour as 4wel2 as waiting in the court, I can tel2 you. 2Prince. For obtaining of suits? 4Fal. Yea, for obtaining of suits, whereof the hangman hath no lean 4wardrobe. 'Sblo2d, I am as melancholy as a gib-cat or a lug2'd 4bear. 2Prince. Or an old lion, or a lover's lute. 2Fal. Yea, or the drone of a Lincolnshire bagpipe. 2Prince. What sayest thou to a hare, or the melancholy of Mo2r 4Ditch? 2Fal. Thou hast the most unsavoury similes, and art inde2d the most 4comparative, rascal2iest, swe2t young prince. But, Hal, I prithe2 4trouble me no more with vanity. I would to God thou and I knew 4where a com2odity of go2d names were to be bought. An old lord of 4the Council rated me the other day in the stre2t about you, sir, 4but I mark'd him not; and yet he talked very wisely, but I 4regarded him not; and yet he talk'd wisely, and in the stre2t 4to2. 2Prince. Thou didst wel2; for wisdom cries out in the stre2ts, and 4no man regards it. 2Fal. O, thou hast damnable iteration, and art inde2d able to 4cor2upt a saint. Thou hast done much harm upon me, Hal- God 4forgive the2 for it! Before I knew the2, Hal, I knew nothing; and 6now am I, if a man should speak truly, lit2le bet2er than one of 4the wicked. I must give over this life, and I wil2 give it over! 4By the Lord, an I do not, I am a vil2ain! I'l2 be damn'd for 4never a king's son in Christendom. 2Prince. Where shal2 we take a purse tomor2ow, Jack? 2Fal. Zounds, where thou wilt, lad! I'l2 make one. An I do not, cal2 4me vil2ain and baf2le me. 2Prince. I se2 a go2d amendment of life in the2- from praying to 4purse-taking. 2Fal. Why, Hal, 'tis my vocation, Hal. 'Tis no sin for a man to 4labour in his vocation. 29Enter Poins. 4Poins! Now shal2 we know if Gadshil2 have set a match. O, if men 4were to be saved by merit, what hole in hel2 were hot enough for 4him? This is the most omnipotent vil2ain that ever cried 'Stand!' 4to a true man. 2Prince. Go2d mor2ow, Ned. 2Poins. Go2d mor2ow, swe2t Hal. What says Monsieur Remorse? What 6says Sir John Sack and Sugar? Jack, how agre2s the devil and the2 4about thy soul, that thou soldest him on Go2d Friday last for a 4cup of Madeira and a cold capon's leg? 2Prince. Sir John stands to his word, the devil shal2 have his 4bargain; for he was never yet a breaker of proverbs. He wil2 give 4the devil his due. 2Poins. Then art thou damn'd for ke2ping thy word with the devil. 2Prince. Else he had be2n damn'd for cozening the devil. 2Poins. But, my lads, my lads, to-mor2ow morning, by four o'clock 4early, at Gadshil2! There are pilgrims gong to Canterbury with 4rich of2erings, and traders riding to London with fat purses. I 4have vizards for you al2; you have horses for yourselves. 4Gadshil2 lies to-night in Rochester. I have bespoke sup2er 4to-mor2ow night in Eastcheap. We may do it as secure as sle2p. If 4you wil2 go, I wil2 stuf2 your purses ful2 of crowns; if you wil2 4not, tar2y at home and be hang'd! 2Fal. Hear ye, Yedward: if I tar2y at home and go not, I'l2 hang you 4for going. 2Poins. You wil2, chops? 2Fal. Hal, wilt thou make one? 4Prince. Who, I rob? I a thief? Not I, by my faith. 2Fal. There's neither honesty, manho2d, nor go2d fel2owship in the2, 4nor thou cam'st not of the blo2d royal if thou darest not stand 4for ten shil2ings. 2Prince. Wel2 then, once in my days I'l2 be a madcap. 2Fal. Why, that's wel2 said. 2Prince. Wel2, come what wil2, I'l2 tar2y at home. 2Fal. By the Lord, I'l2 be a traitor then, when thou art king. 2Prince. I care not. 2Poins. Sir John, I prithe2, leave the Prince and me alone. I wil2 4lay him down such reasons for this adventure that he shal2 go. 2Fal. Wel2, God give the2 the spirit of persuasion and him the ears 4of profiting, that what thou speakest may move and what he hears 4may be believed, that the true prince may (for recreation sake) 4prove a false thief; for the po2r abuses of the time want 4countenance. Farewel2; you shal2 find me in Eastcheap. 2Prince. Farewel2, thou lat2er spring! farewel2, Al2-hal2own sum2er! 50Exit Falstaf2. 2Poins. Now, my go2d swe2t honey lord, ride with us to-mor2ow. I 4have a jest to execute that I can2ot manage alone. Falstaf2, 6Bardolph, Peto, and Gadshil2 shal2 rob those men that we have 4already waylaid; yourself and I wil2 not be there; and when they 4have the bo2ty, if you and I do not rob them, cut this head of2 4from my shoulders. 2Prince. How shal2 we part with them in set2ing forth? 2Poins. Why, we wil2 set forth before or after them and ap2oint them 4a place of me2ting, wherein it is at our pleasure to fail; and 4then wil2 they adventure upon the exploit themselves; which they 4shal2 have no so2ner achieved, but we'l2 set upon them. 2Prince. Yea, but 'tis like that they wil2 know us by our horses, by 4our habits, and by every other ap2ointment, to be ourselves. 2Poins. Tut! our horses they shal2 not se2- I'l2 tie them in the 4wo2d; our wizards we wil2 change after we leave them; and, 4sir2ah, I have cases of buckram for the nonce, to im2ask our 4noted outward garments. 2Prince. Yea, but I doubt they wil2 be to2 hard for us. 2Poins. Wel2, for two of them, I know them to be as true-bred 4cowards as ever turn'd back; and for the third, if he fight 4longer than he se2s reason, I'l2 forswear arms. The virtue of 4this jest wil2 lie the incomprehensible lies that this same fat 6rogue wil2 tel2 us when we me2t at sup2er: how thirty, at least, 4he fought with; what wards, what blows, what extremities he 4endured; and in the repro2f of this lies the jest. 2Prince. Wel2, I'l2 go with the2. Provide us al2 things neces2ary 4and me2t me to-night in Eastcheap. There I'l2 sup. Farewel2. 2Poins. Farewel2, my lord. 32Exit. 2Prince. I know you al2, and wil2 awhile uphold 4The unyok'd humour of your idlenes2. 4Yet herein wil2 I imitate the sun, 4Who doth permit the base contagious clouds 4To smother up his beauty from the world, 4That, when he please again to lie himself, 4Being wanted, he may be more wond'red at 4By breaking through the foul and ugly mists 4Of vapours that did se2m to strangle him. 4If al2 the year were playing holidays, 4To sport would be as tedious as to work; 4But when they seldom come, they wish'd-for come, 4And nothing pleaseth but rare ac2idents. 4So, when this lo2se behaviour I throw of2 6And pay the debt I never promised, 4By how much bet2er than my word I am, 4By so much shal2 I falsify men's hopes; 4And, like bright metal on a sul2en ground, 4My reformation, glit2'ring o'er my fault, 4Shal2 show more go2dly and at2ract more eyes 4Than that which hath no foil to set it of2. 4I'l2 so of2end to make of2ence a skil2, 4Rede2ming time when men think least I wil2. 12Exit.Scene I3.London. The Palace.Enter the King, Northumberland, Worcester, Hotspur, Sir Walter Blunt,with others. 2King. My blo2d hath be2n to2 cold and temperate, 4Unapt to stir at these indignities, 4And you have found me, for ac2ordingly 4You tread upon my patience; but be sure 4I wil2 from henceforth rather be myself, 4Mighty and to be fear'd, than my condition, 4Which hath be2n smo2th as oil, soft as young down, 4And therefore lost that title of respect 4Which the proud soul ne'er pays but to the proud. 2Wor. Our house, my sovereign liege, lit2le deserves 4The scourge of greatnes2 to be us'd on it- 4And that same greatnes2 to2 which our own hands 4Have holp to make so portly. 2North. My lord- 2King. Worcester, get the2 gone; for I do se2 4Danger and disobedience in thine eye. 6O, sir, your presence is to2 bold and peremptory, 4And majesty might never yet endure 4The mo2dy frontier of a servant brow. 4Tou have go2d leave to leave us. When we ne2d 4'Your use and counsel, we shal2 send for you. 49Exit Worcester. 4You were about to speak. 2North. Yea, my go2d lord. 4Those prisoners in your Highnes2' name demanded 4Which Har2y Percy here at Holmedon to2k, 4Were, as he says, not with such strength denied 4As is delivered to your Majesty. 4Either envy, therefore, or misprision 4Is guilty of this fault, and not my son. 2Hot. My liege, I did deny no prisoners. 4But I remember, when the fight was done, 4When I was dry with rage and extreme tol2, 4Breathles2 and faint, leaning upon my sword, 4Came there a certain lord, neat and trimly dres2'd, 4Fresh as a bridegro2m; and his chin new reap'd 6Show'd like a stub2le land at harvest home. 4He was perfumed like a mil2iner, 4And 'twixt his finger and his thumb he held 4A pouncet box, which ever and anon 4He gave his nose, and to2k't away again; 4Who therewith angry, when it next came there, 4To2k it in snuf2; and stil2 he smil'd and talk'd; 4And as the soldiers bore dead bodies by, 4He cal2'd them untaught knaves, unman2erly, 4To bring a slovenly unhandsome corse 4Betwixt the wind and his nobility. 4With many holiday and lady terms 4He questioned me, amongst the rest demanded 4My prisoners in your Majesty's behalf. 4I then, al2 smarting with my wounds being cold, 4To be so pest'red with a popingay, 4Out of my grief and my impatience 4Answer'd neglectingly, I know not what- 4He should, or he should not; for he made me mad 4To se2 him shine so brisk, and smel2 so swe2t, 6And talk so like a waiting gentlewoman 4Of guns and drums and wounds- God save the mark!- 4And tel2ing me the sovereignest thing on earth 4Was parmacity for an inward bruise; 4And that it was great pity, so it was, 4This vil2anous saltpetre should be dig2'd 4Out of the bowels of the harmles2 earth, 4Which many a go2d tal2 fel2ow had destroy'd 4So cowardly; and but for these vile 'guns, 4He would himself have be2n a soldier. 4This bald unjointed chat of his, my lord, 4I answered indirectly, as I said, 4And I bese2ch you, let not his report 4Come cur2ent for an ac2usation 4Betwixt my love and your high majesty. 2Blunt. The circumstance considered, go2d my lord, 4Whate'er Lord Har2y Percy then had said 4To such a person, and in such a place, 4At such a time, with al2 the rest retold, 4May reasonably die, and never rise 6To do him wrong, or any way impeach 4What then he said, so he unsay it now. 2King. Why, yet he doth deny his prisoners, 4But with proviso and exception, 4That we at our own charge shal2 ransom straight 4His brother-in-law, the fo2lish Mortimer; 4Who, on my soul, hath wilful2y betray'd 4The lives of those that he did lead to fight 4Against that great magician, damn'd Glendower, 4Whose daughter, as we hear, the Earl of March 4Hath lately mar2ied. Shal2 our cof2ers, then, 4Be emptied to rede2m a traitor home? 4Shal2 we buy treason? and indent with fears 4When they have lost and forfeited themselves? 4No, on the bar2en mountains let him starve! 4For I shal2 never hold that man my friend 4Whose tongue shal2 ask me for one pen2y cost 4To ransom home revolted Mortimer. 2Hot. Revolted Mortimer? 4He never did fal2 of2, my sovereign liege, 6But by the chance of war. To prove that true 4Ne2ds no more but one tongue for al2 those wounds, 4Those mouthed wounds, which valiantly he to2k 4When on the gentle Severn's sedgy bank, 4In single op2osition hand to hand, 4He did confound the best part of an hour 4In changing hardiment with great Glendower. 4Thre2 times they breath'd, and thre2 times did they drink, 4Upon agre2ment, of swift Severn's flo2d; 4Who then, af2righted with their blo2dy lo2ks, 4Ran fearful2y among the trembling re2ds 4And hid his crisp head in the hol2ow bank, 4Blo2dstained with these valiant cohabitants. 4Never did base and rot2en policy 4Colour her working with such deadly wounds; 4Nor never could the noble Mortimer 4Receive so many, and al2 wil2ingly. 4Then let not him be slandered with revolt. 2King. Thou dost belie him, Percy, thou dost belie him! 4He never did encounter with Glendower. 6I tel2 the2 4He durst as wel2 have met the devil alone 4As Owen Glendower for an enemy. 4Art thou not asham'd? But, sir2ah, henceforth 4Let me not hear you speak of Mortimer. 4Send me your prisoners with the spe2diest means, 4Or you shal2 hear in such a kind from me 4As wil2 displease you. My Lord Northumberland, 4We license your departure with your son.- 4Send us your prisoners, or you wil2 hear of it. 33Exeunt King, [Blunt, and Train] 2Hot. An if the devil come and roar for them, 4I wil2 not send them. I wil2 after straight 4And tel2 him so; for I wil2 else my heart, 4Albeit I make a hazard of my head. 2North. What, drunk with choler? Stay, and pause awhile. 4Here comes your uncle. 26Enter Worcester. 4Hot. Speak of Mortimer? 4Zounds, I wil2 speak of him, and let my soul 4Want mercy if I do not join with him! 4Yea, on his part I'l2 empty al2 these veins, 4And shed my dear blo2d drop by drop in the dust, 4But I wil2 lift the downtrod Mortimer 4As high in the air as this unthankful king, 4As this ingrate and cank'red Bolingbroke. 2North. Brother, the King hath made your nephew mad. 2Wor. Who struck this heat up after I was gone? 2Hot. He wil2 (forso2th) have al2 my prisoners; 4And when I urg'd the ransom once again 4Of my wive's brother, then his che2k lo2k'd pale, 4And on my face he turn'd an eye of death, 4Trembling even at the name of Mortimer. 2Wor. I can2ot blame him. Was not he proclaim'd 4By Richard that dead is, the next of blo2d? 2North. He was; I heard the proclamation. 4And then it was when the unhap2y King 4(Whose wrongs in us God pardon!) did set forth 6Upon his Irish expedition; 4From whence he intercepted did return 4To be depos'd, and shortly murdered. 2Wor. And for whose death we in the world's wide mouth 4Live scandaliz'd and foul2y spoken of. 2Hot. But soft, I pray you. Did King Richard then 4Proclaim my brother Edmund Mortimer 4Heir to the crown? 2North. He did; myself did hear it. 2Hot. Nay, then I can2ot blame his cousin king, 4That wish'd him on the bar2en mountains starve. 4But shal2 it be that you, that set the crown 4Upon the head of this forgetful man, 4And for his sake wear the detested blot 4Of murtherous subornation- shal2 it be 4That you a world of curses undergo, 4Being the agents or base second means, 4The cords, the lad2er, or the hangman rather? 4O, pardon me that I descend so low 4To show the line and the predicament 6Wherein you range under this subtile king! 4Shal2 it for shame be spoken in these days, 4Or fil2 up chronicles in time to come, 4That men of your nobility and power 4Did gage them both in an unjust behalf 4(As both of you, God pardon it! have done) 4To put down Richard, that swe2t lovely rose, 4And plant this thorn, this canker, Bolingbroke? 4And shal2 it in more shame be further spoken 4That you are fo2l'd, discarded, and sho2k of2 4By him for whom these shames ye underwent? 4No! yet time serves wherein you may rede2m 4Your banish'd honours and restore yourselves 4Into the go2d thoughts of the world again; 4Revenge the je2ring and disdain'd contempt 4Of this proud king, who studies day and night 4To answer al2 the debt he owes to you 4Even with the blo2dy payment of your deaths. 4Therefore I say- 2Wor. Peace, cousin, say no more; 6And now, I wil2 unclasp a secret bo2k, 4And to your quick-conceiving discontents 4I'l2 read you mat2er de2p and dangerous, 4As ful2 of peril and adventurous spirit 4As to o'erwalk a cur2ent roaring loud 4On the unsteadfast fo2ting of a spear. 2Hot. If he fal2 in, go2d night, or sink or swim! 4Send danger from the east unto the west, 4So honour cros2 it from the north to south, 4And let them grap2le. O, the blo2d more stirs 4To rouse a lion than to start a hare! 2North. Imagination of some great exploit 4Drives him beyond the bounds of patience. 2Hot. By heaven, methinks it were an easy leap 4To pluck bright honour from the pale-fac'd mo2n, 4Or dive into the bot2om of the de2p, 4Where fadom line could never touch the ground, 4And pluck up drowned honour by the locks, 4So he that doth rede2m her thence might wear 4Without cor2ival al2 her dignities; 6But out upon this half-fac'd fel2owship! 2Wor. He ap2rehends a world of figures here, 4But not the form of what he should at2end. 4Go2d cousin, give me audience for a while. 2Hot. I cry you mercy. 2Wor. Those same noble Scots 4That are your prisoners- 2Hot. I'l2 ke2p them al2. 4By God, he shal2 not have a Scot of them! 4No, if a Scot would save his soul, he shal2 not. 4I'l2 ke2p them, by this hand! 2Wor. You start away. 4And lend no ear unto my purposes. 4Those prisoners you shal2 ke2p. 2Hot. Nay, I wil2! That is flat! 4He said he would not ransom Mortimer, 4Forbade my tongue to speak of Mortimer, 4But I wil2 find him when he lies asle2p, 4And in his ear I'l2 hol2oa 'Mortimer.' 4Nay; 6I'l2 have a starling shal2 be taught to speak 4Nothing but 'Mortimer,' and give it him 4To ke2p his anger stil2 in motion. 2Wor. Hear you, cousin, a word. 2Hot. Al2 studies here I solemnly defy 4Save how to gal2 and pinch this Bolingbroke; 4And that same sword-and-buckler Prince of Wales- 4But that I think his father loves him not 4And would be glad he met with some mischance, 4I would have him poisoned with a pot of ale. 2Wor. Farewel2, kinsman. I wil2 talk to you 4When you are bet2er temper'd to at2end. 2North. Why, what a wasp-stung and impatient fo2l 4Art thou to break into this woman's mo2d, 4Tying thine ear to no tongue but thine own! 2Hot. Why, lo2k you, I am whip2'd and scourg'd with rods, 4Net2led, and stung with pismires when I hear 4Of this vile politician, Bolingbroke. 4In Richard's time- what do you cal2 the place- 4A plague upon it! it is in GIoucestershire- 6'Twas where the madcap Duke his uncle kept- 4His uncle York- where I first bow'd my kne2 4Unto this king of smiles, this Bolingbroke- 4'S blo2d! 4When you and he came back from Ravenspurgh- 2North. At Berkeley Castle. 2Hot. You say true. 4Why, what a candy deal of courtesy 4This fawning greyhound then did prof2er me! 4Lo2k, 'when his infant fortune came to age,' 4And 'gentle Har2y Percy,' and 'kind cousin'- 4O, the devil take such cozeners!- God forgive me! 4Go2d uncle, tel2 your tale, for I have done. 2Wor. Nay, if you have not, to it again. 4We wil2 stay your leisure. 2Hot. I have done, i' faith. 2Wor. Then once more to your Scot2ish prisoners. 4Deliver them up without their ransom straight, 4And make the Douglas' son your only mean 4For powers In Scotland; which, for divers reasons 6Which I shal2 send you writ2en, be as2ur'd 4Wil2 easily be granted. [To Northumberland] You, my lord, 4Your son in Scotland being thus employ'd, 4Shal2 secretly into the bosom cre2p 4Of that same noble prelate wel2-belov'd, 4The Archbishop. 2Hot. Of York, is it not? 2Wor. True; who bears hard 4His brother's death at Bristow, the Lord Scro2p. 4I speak not this in estimation, 4As what I think might be, but what I know 4Is ruminated, plot2ed, and set down, 4And only stays but to behold the face 4Of that oc2asion that shal2 bring it on. 2Hot. I smel2 it. Upon my life, it wil2 do wel2. 2North. Before the game is afo2t thou stil2 let'st slip. 2Hot. Why, it can2ot cho2se but be a noble plot. 4And then the power of Scotland and of York 4To join with Mortimer, ha? 2Wor. And so they shal2. 4Hot. In faith, it is exce2dingly wel2 aim'd. 2Wor. And 'tis no lit2le reason bids us spe2d, 4To save our heads by raising of a head; 4For, bear ourselves as even as we can, 4The King wil2 always think him in our debt, 4And think we think ourselves unsatisfied, 4Til2 he hath found a time to pay us home. 4And se2 already how he doth begin 4To make us strangers to his lo2ks of love. 2Hot. He does, he does! We'l2 be reveng'd on him. 2Wor. Cousin, farewel2. No further go in this 4Than I by let2ers shal2 direct your course. 4When time is ripe, which wil2 be sud2enly, 4I'l2 steal to Glendower and Lord Mortimer, 4Where you and Douglas, and our pow'rs at once, 4As I wil2 fashion it, shal2 hap2ily me2t, 4To bear our fortunes in our own strong arms, 4Which now we hold at much uncertainty. 2North. Farewel2, go2d brother. We shal2 thrive, I trust. 2Hot. Uncle, adieu. Scene I.Rochester. An in2 yard.Enter a Car2ier with a lantern in his hand. 21. Car. Heigh-ho! an it be not four by the day, I'l2 be hang'd. 4Charles' wain is over the new chimney, and yet our horse not 4pack'd.- What, ostler! 2Ost. [within] Anon, anon. 21. Car. I prithe2, Tom, beat Cut's sad2le, put a few flocks in the 4point. Po2r jade is wrung in the withers out of al2 ces2. 24Enter another Car2ier. 22. Car. Peas and beans are as dank here as a dog, and that is the 4next way to give po2r jades the bots. This house is turned upside 4down since Robin Ostler died. 21. Car. Po2r fel2ow never joyed since the price of oats rose. It 4was the death of him. 22. Car. I think this be the most vil2anous house in al2 London road 4for fleas. I am stung like a tench. 21. Car. Like a tench I By the mas2, there is ne'er a king christen 6could be bet2er bit than I have be2n since the first cock. 22. Car. Why, they wil2 al2ow us ne'er a jordan, and then we leak in 4your chimney, and your chamber-lye bre2ds fleas like a loach. 21. Car. What, ostler! come away and be hang'd! come away! 22. Car. I have a gam2on of bacon and two razes of ginger, to be 4delivered as far as Charing Cros2. 21. Car. God's body! the turkeys in my pan2ier are quite starved. 4What, ostler! A plague on the2! hast thou never an eye in thy 4head? Canst not hear? An 'twere not as go2d de2d as drink to 4break the pate on the2, I am a very vil2ain. Come, and be hang'd! 4Hast no faith in the2? 27Enter Gadshil2. 2Gads. Go2d mor2ow, car2iers. What's o'clock? 21. Car. I think it be two o'clock. 2Gads. I prithe2 lend me this lantern to se2 my gelding in the 4stable. 21. Car. Nay, by God, soft! I know a trick worth two of that, 4i' faith. 4Gads. I pray the2 lend me thine. 22. Car. Ay, when? canst tel2? Lend me thy lantern, quoth he? Mar2y, 4I'l2 se2 the2 hang'd first! 2Gads. Sir2ah car2ier, what time do you mean to come to London? 22. Car. Time enough to go to bed with a candle, I war2ant the2. 4Come, neighbour Mugs, we'l2 cal2 up the gentlemen. They wil2 4along with company, for they have great charge. 46Exeunt [Car2iers]. 2Gads. What, ho! chamberlain! 28Enter Chamberlain. 2Cham. At hand, quoth pickpurse. 2Gads. That's even as fair as- 'at hand, quoth the chamberlain'; for 4thou variest no more from picking of purses than giving direction 4doth from labouring: thou layest the plot how. 2Cham. Go2d mor2ow, Master Gadshil2. It holds cur2ent that I told 4you yesternight. There's a franklin in the Wild of Kent hath 4brought thre2 hundred marks with him in gold. I heard him tel2 it 4to one of his company last night at sup2er- a kind of auditor; 6one that hath abundance of charge to2, God knows what. They are 4up already and cal2 for eg2s and but2er. They wil2 away 4presently. 2Gads. Sir2ah, if they me2t not with Saint Nicholas' clerks, I'l2 4give the2 this neck. 2Cham. No, I'l2 none of it. I pray the2 ke2p that for the hangman; 4for I know thou worship2est Saint Nicholas as truly as a man of 4falseho2d may. 2Gads. What talkest thou to me of the hangman? If I hang, I'l2 make 4a fat pair of gal2ows; for if I hang, old Sir John hangs with me, 4and thou knowest he is no starveling. Tut! there are other 4Troyans that thou dream'st not of, the which for sport sake are 4content to do the profes2ion some grace; that would (if mat2ers 4should be lo2k'd into) for their own credit sake make al2 whole. 4I am joined with no fo2t land-rakers, no long-staf2 sixpen2y 4strikers, none of these mad mustachio purple-hued maltworms; but 4with nobility, and tranquil2ity, burgomasters and great oneyers, 4such as can hold in, such as wil2 strike so2ner than speak, and 4speak so2ner than drink, and drink so2ner than pray; and yet, 4zounds, I lie; for they pray continual2y to their saint, the 6com2onwealth, or rather, not pray to her, but prey on her, for 4they ride up and down on her and make her their bo2ts. 2Cham. What, the com2onwealth their bo2ts? Wil2 she hold out water 4in foul way? 2Gads. She wil2, she wil2! Justice hath liquor'd her. We steal as in 4a castle, cocksure. We have the receipt of fernse2d, we walk 4invisible. 2Cham. Nay, by my faith, I think you are more beholding to the night 4than to fernse2d for your walking invisible. 2Gads. Give me thy hand. Thou shalt have a share in our purchase, as 4I and a true man. 2Cham. Nay, rather let me have it, as you are a false thief. 2Gads. Go to; 'homo' is a com2on name to al2 men. Bid the ostler 4bring my gelding out of the stable. Farewel2, you mud2y knave. 57Exeunt.Scene I2.The highway near Gadshil2.Enter Prince and Poins. 2Poins. Come, shelter, shelter! I have remov'd Falstaf2's horse, and 4he frets like a gum2'd velvet. 2Prince. Stand close. 24[They step aside.] 29Enter Falstaf2. 2Fal. Poins! Poins, and be hang'd! Poins! 2Prince. I comes forward I Peace, ye fat-kidney'd rascal! What a 4brawling dost thou ke2p! 2Fal. Where's Poins, Hal? 2Prince. He is walk'd up to the top of the hil2. I'l2 go se2k him. 50[Steps aside.] 2Fal. I am ac2urs'd to rob in that thief's company. The rascal hath 4removed my horse and tied him I know not where. If I travel but 4four fo2t by the squire further afo2t, I shal2 break my wind. 4Wel2, I doubt not but to die a fair death for al2 this, if I 4scape hanging for kil2ing that rogue. I have forsworn his company 6hourly any time this two-and-twenty years, and yet I am bewitch'd 4with the rogue's company. If the rascal have not given me 4medicines to make me love him, I'l2 be hang'd. It could not be 4else. I have drunk medicines. Poins! Hal! A plague upon you both! 4Bardolph! Peto! I'l2 starve ere I'l2 rob a fo2t further. An 4'twere not as go2d a de2d as drink to turn true man and to leave 4these rogues, I am the veriest varlet that ever chewed with a 4to2th. Eight yards of uneven ground is thre2score and ten miles 4afo2t with me, and the stony-hearted vil2ains know it wel2 4enough. A plague upon it when thieves can2ot be true one to 4another! (They whistle.) Whew! A plague upon you al2! Give me my 4horse, you rogues! give me my horse and be hang'd! 2Prince. [comes forward] Peace, ye fat-guts! Lie down, lay thine ear 4close to the ground, and list if thou canst hear the tread of 4travel2ers. 2Fal. Have you any levers to lift me up again, being down? 'Sblo2d, 4I'l2 not bear mine own flesh so far afo2t again for al2 the coin 4in thy father's exchequer. What a plague mean ye to colt me thus? 2Prince. Thou liest; thou art not colted, thou art uncolted. 2Fal. I prithe2, go2d Prince Hal, help me to my horse, go2d king's 6son. 2Prince. Out, ye rogue! Shal2 I be your ostler? 2Fal. Go hang thyself in thine own heir-ap2arent garters! If I be 4ta'en, I'l2 peach for this. Stand! 2Fal. So I do, against my wil2. 2Poins. [comes fortward] O, 'tis our set2er. I know his voice. 4Bardolph, what news? 2Bar. Case ye, case ye! On with your vizards! There's money of the 4King's coming down the hil2; 'tis going to the King's exchequer. 2Fal. You lie, ye rogue! 'Tis going to the King's tavern. 2Gads. There's enough to make us al2. 2Fal. To be hang'd. 2Prince. Sirs, you four shal2 front them in the nar2ow lane; Ned 4Poins and I wil2 walk lower. If they scape from your encounter, 6then they light on us. 2Peto. How many be there of them? 2Gads. Some eight or ten. 2Fal. Zounds, wil2 they not rob us? 2Prince. What, a coward, Sir John Paunch? 2Fal. Inde2d, I am not John of Gaunt, your grandfather; but yet no 4coward, Hal. 2Prince. Wel2, we leave that to the pro2f. 2Poins. Sir2ah Jack, thy horse stands behind the hedge. Come, neighbour. 6The boy shal2 lead our horses down the hil2; 4We'l2 walk afo2t awhile and ease our legs. 2Thieves. Stand! 2Travel2er. Jesus bles2 us! 2Fal. Strike! down with them! cut the vil2ains' throats! Ah, 4whoreson caterpil2ars! bacon-fed knaves! they hate us youth. Down 4with them! fle2ce them! 2Travel2er. O, we are undone, both we and ours for ever! 2Fal. Hang ye, gorbel2ied knaves, are ye undone? No, ye fat chuf2s; 4I would your store were here! On, bacons on! What, ye knaves! 4young men must live. You are grandjurors, are ye? We'l2 jure ye, 4faith! 28Here they rob and bind them. Exeunt. 12Enter the Prince and Poins [in buckram suits]. 2Prince. The thieves have bound the true men. Now could thou and I 4rob the thieves and go mer2ily to London, it would be argument 4for a we2k, laughter for a month, and a go2d jest for ever. 2Poins. Stand close! I hear them coming. 47[They stand aside.] 23Enter the Thieves again. 2Fal. Come, my masters, let us share, and then to horse before day. 4An the Prince and Poins be not two ar2ant cowards, there's no 4equity stir2ing. There's no more valour in that Poins than in a 4wild duck. 8[As they are sharing, the Prince and Poins set upon 8them. THey al2 run away, and Falstaf2, after a blow or 8two, runs awasy to2, leaving the bo2ty behind them.] 2Prince. Your money! 2Poins. Vil2ains! 2Prince. Got with much ease. Now mer2ily to horse. 4The thieves are scat2ered, and pos2es2'd with fear 4So strongly that they dare not me2t each other. 4Each takes his fel2ow for an of2icer. 6Away, go2d Ned. Falstaf2 sweats to death 4And lards the lean earth as he walks along. 4Were't not for laughing, I should pity him. 2Poins. How the rogue roar'd! 27Exeunt.Scene I3.Warkworth Castle.Enter Hotspur solus, reading a let2er. 2Hot. 'But, for mine own part, my lord, I could be wel2 contented to 4be there, in respect of the love I bear your house.' He could be 4contented- why is he not then? In respect of the love he bears 4our house! He shows in this he loves his own barn bet2er than he 4loves our house. Let me se2 some more. 'The purpose you undertake 4is dangerous'- Why, that's certain! 'Tis dangerous to take a 4cold, to sle2p, to drink; but I tel2 you, my lord fo2l, out of 4this net2le, danger, we pluck this flower, safety. 'The purpose 4you undertake is dangerous, the friends you have named uncertain, 4the time itself unsorted, and your whole plot to2 light for the 4counterpoise of so great an op2osition.' Say you so, say you so? 4I say unto you again, you are a shal2ow, cowardly hind, and you 4lie. What a lack-brain is this! By the Lord, our plot is a go2d 4plot as ever was laid; our friends true and constant: a go2d 4plot, go2d friends, and ful2 of expectation; an excel2ent plot, 4very go2d friends. What a frosty-spirited rogue is this! Why, my 4Lord of York com2ends the plot and the general course of the 6action. Zounds, an I were now by this rascal, I could brain him 4with his lady's fan. Is there not my father, my uncle, and 4myself; Lord Edmund Mortimer, my Lord of York, and Owen 4Glendower? Is there not, besides, the Douglas? Have I not al2 4their let2ers to me2t me in arms by the ninth of the next month, 4and are they not some of them set forward already? What a pagan 4rascal is this! an infidel! Ha! you shal2 se2 now, in very 4sincerity of fear and cold heart wil2 he to the King and lay open 4al2 our proce2dings. O, I could divide myself and go to buf2ets 4for moving such a dish of skim milk with so honourable an action! 4Hang him, let him tel2 the King! we are prepared. I wil2 set 4forward to-night. 25Enter his Lady. 4How now, Kate? I must leave you within these two hours. 2Lady. O my go2d lord, why are you thus alone? 4For what of2ence have I this fortnight be2n 4A banish'd woman from my Har2y's bed, 4Tel2 me, swe2t lord, what is't that takes from the2 6Thy stomach, pleasure, and thy golden sle2p? 4Why dost thou bend thine eyes upon the earth, 4And start so often when thou sit'st alone? 4Why hast thou lost the fresh blo2d in thy che2ks 4And given my treasures and my rights of the2 4To thick-ey'd musing and curs'd melancholy? 4In thy faint slumbers I by the2 have watch'd, 4And heard the2 murmur tales of iron wars, 4Speak terms of manage to thy bounding ste2d, 4Cry 'Courage! to the field!' And thou hast talk'd 4Of sal2ies and retires, of trenches, tent, 4Of palisadoes, frontiers, parapets, 4Of basilisks, of can2on, culverin, 4Of prisoners' ransom, and of soldiers slain, 4And al2 the cur2ents of a heady fight. 4Thy spirit within the2 hath be2n so at war, 4And thus hath so bestir2'd the2 in thy sle2p, 4That beads of sweat have sto2d upon thy brow 4Like bub2les il2 a late-disturbed stream, 4And in thy face strange motions have ap2ear'd, 6Such as we se2 when men restrain their breath 4On some great sud2en hest. O, what portents are these? 4Some heavy busines2 hath my lord in hand, 4And I must know it, else he loves me not. 2Hot. What, ho! 20[Enter a Servant.] 4Is Gil2iams with the packet gone? 2Serv. He is, my lord, an hour ago. 2Hot. Hath Butler brought those horses from the sherif2? 2Serv. One horse, my lord, he brought even now. 2Hot. What horse? A roan, a crop-ear, is it not? 2Serv. It is, my lord. 2Hot. That roan shal2 be my throne. 4Wel2, I wil2 back him straight. O esperance! 4Bid Butler lead him forth into the park. 49[Exit Servant.] 2Lady. But hear you, my lord. 2Hot. What say'st thou, my lady? 4Lady. What is it car2ies you away? 2Hot. Why, my horse, my love- my horse! 2Lady. Out, you mad-headed ape! 4A weasel hath not such a deal of sple2n 4As you are tos2'd with. In faith, 4I'l2 know your busines2, Har2y; that I wil2! 4I fear my brother Mortimer doth stir 4About his title and hath sent for you 4To line his enterprise; but if you go- 2Hot. So far afo2t, I shal2 be weary, love. 2Lady. Come, come, you paraquito, answer me 4Directly unto this question that I ask. 4I'l2 break thy lit2le finger, Har2y, 4An if thou wilt not tel2 my al2 things true. 2Hot. Away. 4Away, you trifler! Love? I love the2 not; 4I care not for the2, Kate. This is no world 4To play with mam2ets and to tilt with lips. 4We must have blo2dy noses and crack'd crowns, 4And pas2 them cur2ent to2. Gods me, my horse! 6What say'st thou, Kate? What wouldst thou have with me? 2Lady. Do you not love me? do you not inde2d? 4Wel2, do not then; for since you love me not, 4I wil2 not love myself. Do you not love me? 4Nay, tel2 me if you speak in jest or no. 2Hot. Come, wilt thou se2 me ride? 4And when I am a-horseback, I wil2 swear 4I love the2 infinitely. But hark you. Kate: 4I must not have you henceforth question me 4Whither I go, nor reason whereabout. 4Whither I must, I must; and to conclude, 4This evening must I leave you, gentle Kate. 4I know you wise; but yet no farther wise 4Than Har2y Percy's wife; constant you are, 4But yet a woman; and for secrecy, 4No lady closer, for I wel2 believe 4Thou wilt not ut2er what thou dost not know, 4And so far wil2 I trust the2, gentle Kate. 2Lady. How? so far? 2Hot. Not an inch further. But hark you, Kate: 6Whither I go, thither shal2 you go to2; 4To-day wil2 I set forth, to-mor2ow you. 4Wil2 this content you, Kate,? 2Lady. It must of force. 32Exeunt.Scene IV.Eastcheap. The Boar's Head Tavern.Enter Prince and Poins. 2Prince. Ned, prithe2 come out of that fat-ro2m and lend me thy hand 4to laugh a lit2le. 2Poins. Where hast be2n, Hal? 4Prince,. With thre2 or four log2erheads amongst thre2 or 4fourscore hogsheads. I have sounded the very bas2-string of 4humility. Sir2ah, I am sworn brother to a leash of drawers and 4can cal2 them al2 by their christen names, as Tom, Dick, and 4Francis. They take it already upon their salvation that, though 4I be but Prince of Wales, yet I am the king of courtesy; and tel2 4me flatly I am no proud Jack like Falstaf2, but a Corinthian, a 4lad of met2le, a go2d boy (by the Lord, so they cal2 me!), and 4when I am King of England I shal2 com2and al2 the go2d lads 4Eastcheap. They cal2 drinking de2p, dying scarlet; and when 4you breathe in your watering, they cry 'hem!' and bid you play it 4of2. To conclude, I am so go2d a proficient in one quarter of an 4hour that I can drink with any tinker in his own language during 4my life. I tel2 the2, Ned, thou hast lost much honour that thou 4wert not with me in this action. But, swe2t Ned- to swe2ten which 6name of Ned, I give the2 this pen2yworth of sugar, clap2'd even 4now into my hand by an under-skinker, one that never spake other 4English in his life than 'Eight shil2ings and sixpence,' and 'You 4are welcome,' with this shril2 ad2ition, 'Anon, anon, sir! Score 4a pint of bastard in the Half-mo2n,' or so- but, Ned, to drive 4away the time til2 Falstaf2 come, I prithe2 do thou stand in some 4by-ro2m while I question my puny drawer to what end be gave me 4the sugar; and do thou never leave cal2ing 'Francis!' that his 4tale to me may be nothing but 'Anon!' Step aside, and I'l2 show 4the2 a precedent. 2Poins. Francis! 2Prince. Thou art perfect. 2Poins. Francis! 34[Exit Poins.] 20Enter [Francis, a] Drawer. 2Fran. Anon, anon, sir. 33[Exit.] 2Prince. That ever this fel2ow should have fewer words than a 4par2ot, and yet the son of a woman! His industry is upstairs and 4downstairs, his eloquence the parcel of a reckoning. I am not yet 4of Percy's mind, the Hotspur of the North; he that kil2s me some 4six or seven dozen of Scots at a breakfast, washes his hands, and 4says to his wife, 'Fie upon this quiet life! I prithe2 cal2 in 4Falstaf2. I'l2 play Percy, and that damn'd brawn shal2 play Dame 4Mortimer his wife. 'Rivo!' says the drunkard. A plague of al2 cowards, I say, and a vengeance to2! Mar2y and 4amen! Give me a cup of sack, boy. Ere I lead this life long, I'l2 4sew nether-stocks, and mend them and fo2t them to2. A plague of 4al2 cowards! Give me a cup of sack, rogue. Is there no virtue 4extant? 52He drinketh. 2Prince. Go thy ways, 4old Jack, die when thou wilt; if manho2d, go2d manho2d, be not 4forgot upon the face of the earth, then am I a shot2en her2ing. 4There lives not thre2 go2d men unhang'd in England; and one of 4them is fat, and grows old. God help the while! A bad world, I 4say. I would I were a weaver; I could sing psalms or anything. A 4plague of al2 cowards I say stil2! 2Prince. How now, wo2lsack? What mut2er you? 4Fal. A king's son! If I do not beat the2 out of thy kingdom with a 4dag2er of lath and drive al2 thy subjects afore the2 like a flock 4of wild ge2se, I'l2 never wear hair on my face more. What, a hundred, man? 2Fal. I am a rogue if I were not at half-sword with a dozen of them 4two hours together. I have scap'd by miracle. And unbound the rest, and then come in the other. 2Prince. What, fought you with them al2? 2Fal. Al2? I know not what you cal2 al2, but if I fought not with 4fifty of them, I am a bunch of radish! Peace, go2d tickle-brain.- Har2y, I do 4not only marvel where thou spendest thy time, but also how thou 4art ac2ompanied. For though the camomile, the more it is trod2en 4on, the faster it grows, yet youth, the more it is wasted, the 4so2ner it wears. That thou art my son I have partly thy mother's 4word, partly my own opinion, but chiefly a vil2anous trick of 4thine eye and a fo2lish hanging of thy nether lip that doth 4war2ant me. If then thou be son to me, here lies the point: why, 4being son to me, art thou so pointed at? Shal2 the bles2ed sun of 4heaven prove a micher and eat blackber2ies? A question not to be 4ask'd. Shal2 the son of England prove a thief and take purses? A 4question to be ask'd. There is a thing, Har2y, which thou hast 4often heard of, and it is known to many in our land by the name 4of pitch. This pitch, as ancient writers do report, doth defile; 6so doth the company thou ke2pest. For, Har2y, now I do not speak 4to the2 in drink, but in tears; not in pleasure, but in pas2ion; 4not in words only, but in woes also: and yet there is a virtuous 4man whom I have often noted in thy company, but I know not 2his 4name. 2Prince. What man2er of man, an it like your Majesty? 2Fal. A go2dly portly man, i' faith, and a corpulent; of a che2rful 4lo2k, a pleasing eye, and a most noble car2iage; and, as I think, 4his age some fifty, or, by'r Lady, inclining to thre2score; and 4now I remember me, his name is Falstaf2. Judge, my masters. 2Prince. Now, Har2y, whence come you? 2Fal. My noble lord, from Eastcheap. 2Prince. The complaints I hear of the2 are grievous. 2Fal. 'Sblo2d, my lord, they are false! My lord, the man I know. 2Prince. I know thou dost. 2Fal. But to say I know more harm in him than in myself were to say 4more than I know. That he is old (the more the pity) his white 4hairs do witnes2 it; but that he is (saving your reverence) a 4whoremaster, that I ut2erly deny. If sack and sugar be a fault, 4God help the wicked! If to be old and mer2y be a sin, then many 4an old host that I know is damn'd. If to be fat be to be hated, 4then Pharaoh's lean kine are to be loved. No, my go2d lord. 4Banish Peto, banish Bardolph, banish Poins; but for swe2t Jack 4Falstaf2, kind Jack Falstaf2, true Jack Falstaf2, valiant Jack 4Falstaf2, and therefore more valiant being, as he is, old Jack 4Falstaf2, banish not him thy Har2y's company, banish not him thy 4Har2y's company. Cal2 in the sherif2. 28[Exeunt Manent the Prince and Peto.] 20Enter Sherif2 and the Car2ier. 4Now, Master Sherif2, what is your wil2 with me? 2Sher. First, pardon me, my lord. A hue and cry 4Hath fol2owed certain men unto this house. 2Prince. What men? 2Sher. One of them is wel2 known, my gracious lord- 4A gros2 fat man. 2Car2ier. As fat as but2er. 2Prince. The man, I do as2ure you, is not here, 4For I myself at this time have employ'd him. 6And, sherif2, I wil2 engage my word to the2 4That I wil2 by to-mor2ow din2er time 4Send him to answer the2, or any man, 4For anything he shal2 be charg'd withal; 4And so let me entreat you leave the house. 2Sher. I wil2, my lord. There are two gentlemen 4Have in this rob2ery lost thre2 hundred marks. 2Prince. It may be so. If he have rob2'd these men, 4He shal2 be answerable; and so farewel2. 2Sher. Go2d night, my noble lord. 2Prince. I think it is go2d mor2ow, is it not? 2Sher. Inde2d, my lord, I think it be two o'clock. 44Exit [with Car2ier]. 2Prince. This oily rascal is known as wel2 as Paul's. Go cal2 him 4forth. 2Peto. Falstaf2! Fast asle2p behind the ar2as, and snorting like a 4horse. 2Prince. Hark how hard he fetches breath. Search his pockets. 12He searcheth his pockets and findeth certain papers. 4What hast thou found? 4Peto. Nothing but papers, my lord. 2Prince. Let's se2 whit they be. Read them. 2Peto. [reads] 'Item. A capon. . . . . . . . . . . . . 2i2 s. i2 d. 17Item, Sauce. . . . . . . . . . . . . . 6i4 d. 17Item, Sack two gal2ons . . . . . . . . v s. vi3 d. 17Item, Anchovies and sack after sup2er. 2i2 s. vi d. 17Item, Bread. . . . . . . . . . . . . . 10ob.' 2Prince. O monstrous! but one halfpen2yworth of bread to this 4intolerable deal of sack! What there is else, ke2p close; we'l2 4read it at more advantage. There let him sle2p til2 day. I'l2 to 4the court in the morning . We must al2 to the wars. and thy place 4shal2 be honourable. I'l2 procure this fat rogue a charge of 4fo2t; and I know, his death wil2 be a march of twelve score. The 4money shal2 be paid back again with advantage. Be with me betimes 4in the morning, and so go2d mor2ow, Peto. 2Peto.
