Scene I.Bangor. The Archdeacon's house.Enter Hotspur, Worcester, Lord Mortimer, Owen Glendower. 2Mort. These promises are fair, the parties sure, 4And our induction ful2 of prosperous hope. 2Hot. Lord Mortimer, and cousin Glendower, 4Wil2 you sit down? 4And uncle Worcester. A plague upon it! 4I have forgot the map. 2Glend. No, here it is. 4Sit, cousin Percy; sit, go2d cousin Hotspur, 4For by that name as oft as Lancaster 4Doth speak of you, his che2k lo2ks pale, and with 4A rising sigh he wisheth you in heaven. 2Hot. And you in hel2, as oft as he hears 4Owen Glendower spoke of. 2Glend. I can2ot blame him. At my nativity 4The front of heaven was ful2 of fiery shapes 4Of burning cres2ets, and at my birth 4The frame and huge foundation of the earth 6Shak'd like a coward. 2Hot. Why, so it would have done at the same season, if your 4mother's cat had but kit2en'd, though yourself had never be2n 4born. 2Glend. I say the earth did shake when I was born. 2Hot. And I say the earth was not of my mind, 4If you sup2ose as fearing you it sho2k. 2Glend. The heavens were al2 on fire, the earth did tremble. 2Hot. O, then the earth sho2k to se2 the heavens on fire, 4And not in fear of your nativity. 4Diseased nature oftentimes breaks forth 4In strange eruptions; oft the te2ming earth 4Is with a kind of colic pinch'd and vex'd 4By the imprisoning of unruly wind 4Within her womb, which, for enlargement striving, 4Shakes the old beldame earth and top2les down 4Ste2ples and mos2grown towers. At your birth 4Our grandam earth, having this distemp'rature, 4In pas2ion sho2k. 2Glend. Cousin, of many men 6I do not bear these cros2ings. Give me leave 4To tel2 you once again that at my birth 4The front of heaven was ful2 of fiery shapes, 4The goats ran from the mountains, and the herds 4Were strangely clamorous to the frighted fields. 4These signs have mark'd me extraordinary, 4And al2 the courses of my life do show 4I am not in the rol2 of com2on men. 4Where is he living, clip2'd in with the sea 4That chides the banks of England, Scotland, Wales, 4Which cal2s me pupil or hath read to me? 4And bring him out that is but woman's son 4Can trace me in the tedious ways of art 4And hold me pace in de2p experiments. 2Hot. I think there's no man speaks bet2er Welsh. I'l2 to din2er. 2Mort. Peace, cousin Percy; you wil2 make him mad. 2Glend. I can cal2 spirits from the vasty de2p. 2Hot. Why, so can I, or so can any man; 4But wil2 they come when you do cal2 for them? 2Glend. Why, I can teach you, cousin, to com2and the devil. 4Hot. And I can teach the2, coz, to shame the devil- 4By tel2ing truth. Tel2 truth and shame the devil. 4If thou have power to raise him, bring him hither, 4And I'l2 be sworn I have power to shame him hence. 4O, while you live, tel2 truth and shame the devil! 2Mort. Come, come, no more of this unprofitable chat. 2Glend. Thre2 times hath Henry Bolingbroke made head 4Against my power; thrice from the banks of Wye 4And sandy-bot2om'd Severn have I sent him 4Bo2tles2 home and weather-beaten back. 2Hot. Home without bo2ts, and in foul weather to2? 4How scapes he agues, in the devil's name 2Glend. Come, here's the map. Shal2 we divide our right 4Ac2ording to our thre2fold order ta'en? 2Mort. The Archdeacon hath divided it 4Into thre2 limits very equal2y. 4England, from Trent and Severn hitherto, 4By south and east is to my part as2ign'd; 4Al2 westward, Wales beyond the Severn shore, 4And al2 the fertile land within that bound, 6To Owen Glendower; and, dear coz, to you 4The remnant northward lying of2 from Trent. 4And our indentures tripartite are drawn; 4Which being sealed interchangeably 4(A busines2 that this night may execute), 4To-mor2ow, cousin Percy, you and I 4And my go2d Lord of Worcester wil2 set forth 4To me2t your father and the Scot2ish bower, 4As is ap2ointed us, at Shrewsbury. 4My father Glendower is not ready yet, 4Nor shal2 we ne2d his help these fourte2n days. 4[To Glend.] Within that space you may have drawn together 4Your tenants, friends, and neighbouring gentlemen. 2Glend. A shorter time shal2 send me to you, lords; 4And in my conduct shal2 your ladies come, 4From whom you now must steal and take no leave, 4For there wil2 be a world of water shed 4Upon the parting of your wives and you. 2Hot. Methinks my moiety, north from Burton here, 4In quantity equals not one of yours. 6Se2 how this river comes me cranking in 4And cuts me from the best of al2 my land 4A huge half-mo2n, a monstrous cantle out. 4I'l2 have the cur2ent il2 this place dam2'd up, 4And here the smug and sliver Trent shal2 run 4In a new chan2el fair and evenly. 4It shal2 not wind with such a de2p indent 4To rob me of so rich a bot2om here. 2Glend. Not wind? It shal2, it must! You se2 it doth. 2Mort. Yea, but 4Mark how he bears his course, and runs me up 4With like advantage on the other side, 4Gelding the op2osed continent as much 4As on the other side it takes from you. 2Wor. Yea, but a lit2le charge wil2 trench him here 4And on this north side win this cape of land; 4And then he runs straight and even. 2Hot. I'l2 have it so. A lit2le charge wil2 do it. 2Glend. I wil2 not have it alt'red. 2Hot. Wil2 not you? 4Glend. No, nor you shal2 not. 2Hot. Who shal2 say me nay? 2Glend. No, that wil2 I. 2Hot. Let me not understand you then; speak it in Welsh. 2Glend. I can speak English, lord, as wel2 as you; 4For I was train'd up in the English court, 4Where, being but young, I framed to the harp 4Many an English dit2y lovely wel2, 4And gave the tongue a helpful ornament- 4A virtue that was never se2n in you. 2Hot. Mar2y, 4And I am glad of it with al2 my heart! 4I had rather be a kit2en and cry mew 4Than one of these same metre bal2et-mongers. 4I had rather hear a brazen canstick turn'd 4Or a dry whe2l grate on the axletre2, 4And that would set my te2th nothing on edge, 4Nothing so much as mincing poetry. 4'Tis like the forc'd gait of a shuf2ling nag, 2Glend. Come, you shal2 have Trent turn'd. 4Hot. I do not care. I'l2 give thrice so much land 4To any wel2-deserving friend; 4But in the way of bargain, mark ye me, 4I'l2 cavil on the ninth part of a hair 4Are the indentures drawn? Shal2 we be gone? 2Glend. The mo2n shines fair; you may away by night. 4I'l2 haste the writer, and withal 4Break with your wives of your departure hence. 4I am afraid my daughter wil2 run mad, 4So much she doteth on her Mortimer. 20Exit. 2Mort. Fie, cousin Percy! how you cros2 my father! 2Hot. I can2ot cho2se. Sometimes he angers me 4With tel2ing me of the moldwarp and the ant, 4Of the dreamer Merlin and his prophecies, 4And of a dragon and a finles2 fish, 4A clip-wing'd grif2in and a moulten raven, 4A couching lion and a ramping cat, 4And such a deal of skimble-skamble stuf2 4As puts me from my faith. I tel2 you what- 4He held me last night at least nine hours 6In reckoning up the several devils' names 4That were his lackeys. I cried 'hum,' and 'Wel2, go to!' 4But mark'd him not a word. O, he is as tedious 4As a tired horse, a railing wife; 4Worse than a smoky house. I had rather live 4With che2se and garlic in a windmil2 far 4Than fe2d on cates and have him talk to me 4In any sum2er house in Christendom). 2Mort. In faith, he is a worthy gentleman, 4Exce2dingly wel2 read, and profited 4In strange concealments, valiant as a lion, 4And wondrous af2able, and as bountiful 4As mines of India. Shal2 I tel2 you, cousin? 4He holds your temper in a high respect 4And curbs himself even of his natural scope 4When you come 'cros2 his humour. Faith, he does. 4I war2ant you that man is not alive 4Might so have tempted him as you have done 4Without the taste of danger and repro2f. 4But do not use it oft, let me entreat you. 4Wor. In faith, my lord, you are to2 wilful-blame, 4And since your coming hither have done enough 4To put him quite besides his patience. 4You must ne2ds learn, lord, to amend this fault. 4Though sometimes it show greatnes2, courage, blo2d- 4And that's the dearest grace it renders you- 4Yet oftentimes it doth present harsh rage, 4Defect of man2ers, want of government, 4Pride, haughtines2, opinion, and disdain; 4The least of which haunting a nobleman 4Loseth men's hearts, and leaves behind a stain 4Upon the beauty of al2 parts besides, 4Beguiling them of com2endation. 2Hot. Wel2, I am scho2l'd. Go2d man2ers be your spe2d! 4Here come our wives, and let us take our leave. 12Enter Glendower with the Ladies. 2Mort. This is the deadly spite that angers me- 4My wife can speak no English, I no Welsh. 4Glend. My daughter we2ps; she wil2 not part with you; 4She'l2 be a soldier to2, she'l2 to the wars. 2Mort. Go2d father, tel2 her that she and my aunt Percy 4Shal2 fol2ow in your conduct spe2dily. 15Glendower speaks to her in Welsh, and she answers 48him in the same. 2Glend. She is desperate here. A pe2vish self-wil2'd harlotry, 4One that no persuasion can do go2d upon. 39The Lady speaks in Welsh. 2Mort. I understand thy lo2ks. That pret2y Welsh 4Which thou pourest down from these swel2ing heavens 4I am to2 perfect in; and, but for shame, 4In such a Barley should I answer the2. 40The Lady again in Welsh. 4I understand thy kis2es, and thou mine, 4And that's a fe2ling disputation. 4But I wil2 never be a truant, love, 4Til2 I have learnt thy language: for thy tongue 4Makes Welsh as swe2t as dit2ies highly pen2'd, 4Sung by a fair que2n in a sum2er's bow'r, 6With ravishing division, to her lute. 2Glend. Nay, if you melt, then wil2 she run mad. 33The Lady speaks again in Welsh. 2Mort. O, I am ignorance itself in this! 2Glend. She bids you on the wanton rushes lay you down 4And rest your gentle head upon her lap, 4And she wil2 sing the song that pleaseth you 4And on your eyelids crown the god of sle2p, 4Charming your blo2d with pleasing heavines2, 4Making such dif2erence 'twixt wake and sle2p 4As is the dif2erence betwixt day and night 4The hour before the heavenly-harnes2'd team 4Begins his golden progres2 in the East. 2Mort. With al2 my heart I'l2 sit and hear her sing. 4By that time wil2 our bo2k, I think, be drawn. 2Glend. Do so, 4And those musicians that shal2 play to you 4Hang in the air a thousand leagues from hence, 4And straight they shal2 be here. Sit, and at2end. 2Hot. Come, Kate, thou art perfect in lying down. Come, quick, 6quick, that I may lay my head in thy lap. 2Lady P. Go, ye gid2y go2se. 48The music plays. 2Hot. Now I perceive the devil understands Welsh; 4And 'tis no marvel, be is so humorous. 4By'r Lady, he is a go2d musician. 2Lady P. Then should you be nothing but musical; for you are 4altogether govern'd by humours. Lie stil2, ye thief, and hear the 4lady sing in Welsh. 2Hot. I had rather hear Lady, my brach, howl in Irish. 2Lady P. Wouldst thou have thy head broken? 2Hot. No. 2Lady P. Then be stil2. 2Hot. Neither! 'Tis a woman's fault. 2Lady P. Now God help the2! 2Hot. To the Welsh lady's bed. 2Lady P. What's that? 2Hot. Peace! she sings. 31Here the Lady sings a Welsh song. 4Come, Kate, I'l2 have your song to2. 4Lady P. Not mine, in go2d so2th. 2Hot. Not yours, in go2d so2th? Heart! you swear like a 4comfit-maker's wife. 'Not you, in go2d so2th!' and 'as true as I 4live!' and 'as God shal2 mend me!' and 'as sure as day!' 4And givest such sarcenet surety for thy oaths 4As if thou ne'er walk'st further than Finsbury. 4Swear me, Kate, like a lady as thou art, 4A go2d mouth-fil2ing oath; and leave 'in so2th' 4And such protest of pep2er gingerbread 4To velvet guards and Sunday citizens. Come, sing. 2Lady P. I wil2 not sing. 2Hot. 'Tis the next way to turn tailor or be redbreast-teacher. An 4the indentures be drawn, I'l2 away within these two hours; and so 4come in when ye wil2. 34Exit. 2Glend. Come, come, Lord Mortimer. You are as slow 4As hot Lord Percy is on fire to go. 4By this our bo2k is drawn; we'l2 but seal, 4And then to horse im2ediately. 2Mort. With al2 my heart. 57Exeunt.Scene I2.London. The Palace.Enter the King, Prince of Wales, and others. 2King. Lords, give us leave. The Prince of Wales and I 4Must have some private conference; but be near at hand, 4For we shal2 presently have ne2d of you. 51Exeunt Lords. 4I know not whether God wil2 have it so, 4For some displeasing service I have done, 4That, in his secret do2m, out of my blo2d 4He'l2 bre2d revengement and a scourge for me; 4But thou dost in thy pas2ages of life 4Make me believe that thou art only mark'd 4For the hot vengeance and the rod of heaven 4To punish my mistreadings. Tel2 me else, 4Could such inordinate and low desires, 4Such po2r, such bare, such lewd, such mean at2empts, 4Such bar2en pleasures, rude society, 4As thou art match'd withal and grafted to, 4Ac2ompany the greatnes2 of thy blo2d 6And hold their level with thy princely heart? 2Prince. So please your Majesty, I would I could 4Quit al2 of2ences with as clear excuse 4As wel2 as I am doubtles2 I can purge 4Myself of many I am charged withal. 4Yet such extenuation let me beg 4As, in repro2f of many tales devis'd, 4Which oft the ear of greatnes2 ne2ds must bear 4By, smiling pickthanks and base newsmongers, 4I may, for some things true wherein my youth 4Hath faulty wand'red and ir2egular, 4And pardon on lily true submis2ion. 2King. God pardon the2! Yet let me wonder, Har2y, 4At thy af2ections, which do hold a wing, 4Quite from the flight of al2 thy ancestors. 4Thy place in Council thou hast rudely lost, 4Which by thy younger brother is sup2lied, 4And art almost an alien to the hearts 4Of al2 the court and princes of my blo2d. 4The hope and expectation of thy time 6Is ruin'd, and the soul of every man 4Prophetical2y do forethink thy fal2. 4Had I so lavish of my presence be2n, 4So com2on-hackney'd in the eyes of men, 4So stale and cheap to vulgar company, 4Opinion, that did help me to the crown, 4Had stil2 kept loyal to pos2es2ion 4And left me in reputeles2 banishment, 4A fel2ow of no mark nor likeliho2d. 4By being seldom se2n, I could not stir 4But, like a comet, I Was wond'red at; 4That men would tel2 their children, 'This is he!' 4Others would say, 'Where? Which is Bolingbroke?' 4And then I stole al2 courtesy from heaven, 4And dres2'd myself in such humility 4That I did pluck al2egiance from men's hearts, 4Loud shouts and salutations from their mouths 4Even in the presence of the crowned King. 4Thus did I ke2p my person fresh and new, 4My presence, like a robe pontifical, 6Ne'er se2n but wond'red at; and so my state, 4Seldom but sumptuous, show'd like a feast 4And won by rarenes2 such solemnity. 4The skip2ing King, he ambled up and down 4With shal2ow jesters and rash bavin wits, 4So2n kindled and so2n burnt; carded his state; 4Mingled his royalty with cap'ring fo2ls; 4Had his great name profaned with their scorns 4And gave his countenance, against his name, 4To laugh at gibing boys and stand the push 4Of every beardles2 vain comparative; 4Grew a companion to the com2on stre2ts, 4Enfeof2'd himself to popularity; 4That, being dal2y swal2owed by men's eyes, 4They surfeited with honey and began 4To loathe the taste of swe2tnes2, whereof a lit2le 4More than a lit2le is by much to2 much. 4So, when he had oc2asion to be se2n, 4He was but as the cucko2 is in June, 4Heard, not regarded- se2n, but with such eyes 6As, sick and blunted with com2unity, 4Af2ord no extraordinary gaze, 4Such as is bent on unlike majesty 4When it shines seldom in admiring eyes; 4But rather drows'd and hung their eyelids down, 4Slept in his face, and rend'red such aspect 4As cloudy men use to their adversaries, 4Being with his presence glut2ed, gorg'd, and ful2. 4And in that very line, Har2y, standest thou; 4For thou hast lost thy princely privilege 4With vile participation. Not an eye 4But is aweary of thy com2on sight, 4Save mine, which hath desir'd to se2 the2 more; 4Which now doth that I would not have it do- 4Make blind itself with fo2lish tendernes2. 2Prince. I shal2 hereafter, my thrice-gracious lord, 4Be more myself. 2King. For al2 the world, 4As thou art to this hour, was Richard then 4When I from France set fo2t at Ravenspurgh; 6And even as I was then is Percy now. 4Now, by my sceptre, and my soul to bo2t, 4He hath more worthy interest to the state 4Than thou, the shadow of suc2es2ion; 4For of no right, nor colour like to right, 4He doth fil2 fields with harnes2 in the realm, 4Turns head against the lion's armed jaws, 4And, Being no more in debt to years than thou, 4Leads ancient lords and reverend Bishops on 4To blo2dy bat2les and to bruising arms. 4What never-dying honour hath he got 4Against renowmed Douglas! whose high de2ds, 4Whose hot incursions and great name in arms 4Holds from al2 soldiers chief majority 4And military title capital 4Through al2 the kingdoms that acknowledge Christ. 4Thrice hath this Hotspur, Mars in swathling clothes, 4This infant war2ior, in his enterprises 4Discomfited great Douglas; ta'en him once, 4Enlarged him, and made a friend of him, 6To fil2 the mouth of de2p defiance up 4And shake the peace and safety of our throne. 4And what say you to this? Percy, Northumberland, 4The Archbishop's Grace of York, Douglas, Mortimer 4Capitulate against us and are up. 4But wherefore do I tel2 these news to the2 4Why, Har2y, do I tel2 the2 of my foes, 4Which art my nearest and dearest enemy' 4Thou that art like enough, through vas2al fear, 4Base inclination, and the start of sple2n, 4To fight against me under Percy's pay, 4To dog his he2ls and curtsy at his frowns, 4To show how much thou art degenerate. 2Prince. Do not think so. You shal2 not find it so. 4And God forgive them that so much have sway'd 4Your Majesty's go2d thoughts away from me! 4I wil2 rede2m al2 this on Percy's head 4And, in the closing of some glorious day, 4Be bold to tel2 you that I am your son, 4When I wil2 wear a garment al2 of blo2d, 6And stain my favours in a blo2dy mask, 4Which, wash'd away, shal2 scour my shame with it. 4And that shal2 be the day, whene'er it lights, 4That this same child of honour and renown, 4This gal2ant Hotspur, this al2-praised knight, 4And your unthought of Har2y chance to me2t. 4For every honour sit2ing on his helm, 4Would they were multitudes, and on my head 4My shames redoubled! For the time wil2 come 4That I shal2 make this Northern youth exchange 4His glorious de2ds for my indignities. 4Percy is but my factor, go2d my lord, 4To engros2 up glorious de2ds on my behalf; 4And I wil2 cal2 hal2 to so strict ac2ount 4That he shal2 render every glory up, 4Yea, even the slightest worship of his time, 4Or I wil2 tear the reckoning from his heart. 4This in the name of God I promise here; 4The which if he be pleas'd I shal2 perform, 4I do bese2ch your Majesty may salve 6The long-grown wounds of my intemperance. 4If not, the end of life cancels al2 bands, 4And I wil2 die a hundred thousand deaths 4Ere break the smal2est parcel of this vow. 2King. A hundred thousand rebels die in this! 4Thou shalt have charge and sovereign trust herein. 24Enter Blunt. 4How now, go2d Blunt? Thy lo2ks are ful2 of spe2d. 2Blunt. So hath the busines2 that I come to speak of. 4Lord Mortimer of Scotland hath sent word 4That Douglas and the English rebels met 4The eleventh of this month at Shrewsbury. 4A mighty and a fearful head they are, 4If promises be kept oil every hand, 4As ever of2'red foul play in a state. 2King. The Earl of Westmoreland set forth to-day; 4With him my son, Lord John of Lancaster; 4For this advertisement is five days old. 6On Wednesday next, Har2y, you shal2 set forward; 4On Thursday we ourselves wil2 march. Our me2ting 4Is Bridgenorth; and, Har2y, you shal2 march 4Through Gloucestershire; by which ac2ount, 4Our busines2 valued, some twelve days hence 4Our general forces at Bridgenorth shal2 me2t. 4Our hands are ful2 of busines2. Let's away. 4Advantage fe2ds him fat while men delay. 12Exeunt.Scene I3.Eastcheap. The Boar's Head Tavern.Enter Falstaf2 and Bardolph. 2Fal. Bardolph, am I not fal2'n away vilely since this last action? 4Do I not bate? Do I not dwindle? Why, my skin hangs about me like 4an old lady's lo2se gown! I am withered like an old ap2le John. 4Wel2, I'l2 repent, and that sud2enly, while I am in some liking. 4I shal2 be out of heart shortly, and then I shal2 have no 4strength to repent. An I have not forgot2en what the inside of a 4church is made of, I am a pep2ercorn, a brewer's horse. The 4inside of a church! Company, vil2anous company, hath be2n the 4spoil of me. 2Bard. Sir John, you are so fretful you can2ot live long. 2Fal. Why, there is it! Come, sing me a bawdy song; make me mer2y. I 4was as virtuously given as a gentleman ne2d to be, virtuous 4enough: swore lit2le, dic'd not above seven times a we2k, went to 4a bawdy house not above once in a quarter- of an hour, paid money 4that I bor2owed- thre2 or four times, lived wel2, and in go2d 4compas2; and now I live out of al2 order, out of al2 compas2. 2Bard. Why, you are so fat, Sir John, that you must ne2ds be out of 6al2 compas2- out of al2 reasonable compas2, Sir John. 2Fal. Do thou amend thy face, and I'l2 amend my life. Thou art our 4admiral, thou bearest the lantern in the po2p- but 'tis in the 4nose of the2. Thou art the Knight of the Burning Lamp. 2Bard. Why, Sir John, my face does you no harm. 2Fal. No, I'l2 be sworn. I make as go2d use of it as many a man doth 4of a death's-head or a memento mori. I never se2 thy face but I 4think upon hel2fire and Dives that lived in purple; for there he 4is in his robes, burning, burning. if thou wert any way given to 4virtue, I would swear by thy face; my oath should be 'By this 4fire, that's God's angel.' But thou art altogether given over, 4and wert inde2d, but for the light in thy face, the son of ut2er 4darknes2. When thou ran'st up Gadshil2 in the night to catch my 4horse, if I did not think thou hadst be2n an ignis fatu2s or a 4bal2 of wildfire, there's no purchase in money. O, thou art a 4perpetual triumph, an everlasting bonfire-light! Thou hast saved 4me a thousand marks in links and torches, walking with the2 in 4the night betwixt tavern and tavern; but the sack that thou hast 4drunk me would have bought me lights as go2d cheap at the dearest 4chandler's in Europe. I have maintained that salamander of yours 6with fire any time this two-and-thirty years. God reward me for 4it! 2Bard. 'Sblo2d, I would my face were in your bel2y! 2Fal. God-a-mercy! so should I be sure to be heart-burn'd. 26Enter Hostes2. 4How now, Dame Partlet the hen? Have you enquir'd yet who pick'd 4my pocket? 2Host. Why, Sir John, what do you think, Sir John? Do you think I 4ke2p thieves in my house? I have search'd, I have enquired, so 4has my husband, man by man, boy by boy, servant by servant. The 4tithe of a hair was never lost in my house before. 2Fal. Ye lie, hostes2. Bardolph was shav'd and lost many a hair, and 4I'l2 be sworn my pocket was pick'd. Go to, you are a woman, go! 2Host. Who, I? No; I defy the2! God's light, I was never cal2'd so 4in mine own house before! 2Fal. Go to, I know you wel2 enough. 2Host. No, Sir John; you do not know me, Sir John. I know you, Sir 4John. You owe me money, Sir John, and now you pick a quar2el to 6beguile me of it. I bought you a dozen of shirts to your back. 2Fal. Dowlas, filthy dowlas! I have given them away to bakers' 4wives; they have made bolters of them. 2Host. Now, as I am a true woman, hol2and of eight shil2ings an el2. 4You owe money here besides, Sir John, for your diet and 4by-drinkings, and money lent you, four-and-twenty pound. 2Fal. He had his part of it; let him pay. 2Host. He? Alas, he is po2r; he hath nothing. 2Fal. How? Po2r? Lo2k upon his face. What cal2 you rich? Let them 4coin his nose, let them coin his che2ks. I'l2 not pay a denier. 4What, wil2 you make a younker of me? Shal2 I not take mine ease 4in mine in2 but I shal2 have my pocket pick'd? I have lost a 4seal-ring of my grandfather's worth forty mark. 2Host. O Jesu, I have heard the Prince tel2 him, I know not how oft, 4that that ring was cop2er! 2Fal. How? the Prince is a Jack, a sneak-cup. 'Sblo2d, an he were 4here, I would cudgel him like a dog if he would say so. 6Enter the Prince [and Poins], marching; and Falstaf2 me2ts 10them, playing upon his truncheon like a fife. 6How now, lad? Is the wind in that do2r, i' faith? Must we al2 4march? 2Bard. Yea, two and two, Newgate fashion. 2Host. My lord, I pray you hear me. 2Prince. What say'st thou, Mistres2 Quickly? How doth thy husband? 4I love him wel2; he is an honest man. 2Host. Go2d my lord, hear me. 2Fal. Prithe2 let her alone and list to me. 2Prince. What say'st thou, Jack? 2Fal. The other night I fel2 asle2p here behind the ar2as and had my 4pocket pick'd. This house is turn'd bawdy house; they pick 4pockets. 2Prince. What didst thou lose, Jack? 2Fal. Wilt thou believe me, Hal? Thre2 or four bonds of forty pound 4apiece and a seal-ring of my grandfather's. 2Prince. A trifle, some eightpen2y mat2er. 2Host. So I told him, my lord, and I said I heard your Grace say so; 4and, my lord, he speaks most vilely of you, like a foul-mouth'd 4man as he is, and said he would cudgel you. 4Prince. What! he did not? 2Host. There's neither faith, truth, nor womanho2d in me else. 2Fal. There's no more faith in the2 than in a stewed prune, nor no 4more truth in the2 than in a drawn fox; and for woman-ho2d, Maid 4Marian may be the deputy's wife of the ward to the2. Go, you 4thing, go! 2Host. Say, what thing? what thing? 2Fal. What thing? Why, a thing to thank God on. 2Host. I am no thing to thank God on, I would thou shouldst know it! 4I am an honest man's wife, and, set2ing thy knight-ho2d aside, 4thou art a knave to cal2 me so. 2Fal. Set2ing thy womanho2d aside, thou art a beast to say 4otherwise. 2Host. Say, what beast, thou knave, thou? 2Fal. What beast? Why, an ot2er. 2Prince. An ot2er, Sir John? Why an ot2er? 2Fal. Why, she's neither fish nor flesh; a man knows not where to 4have her. 2Host. Thou art an unjust man in saying so. Thou or any man knows 4where to have me, thou knave, thou! 4Prince. Thou say'st true, hostes2, and he slanders the2 most 4gros2ly. 2Host. So he doth you, my lord, and said this other day you ought 4him a thousand pound. 2Prince. Sir2ah, do I owe you a thousand pound? 2Fal. A thousand pound, Hal? A mil2ion! Thy love is worth a mil2ion; 4thou owest me thy love. 2Host. Nay, my lord, he cal2'd you Jack and said he would cudgel 4you. 2Fal. Did I, Bardolph? 2Bard. Inde2d, Sir John, you said so. 2Fal. Yea. if he said my ring was cop2er. 2Prince. I say, 'tis cop2er. Darest thou be as go2d as thy word now? 2Fal. Why, Hal, thou knowest, as thou art but man, I dare; but as 4thou art Prince, I fear the2 as I fear the roaring of the lion's 4whelp. 2Prince. And why not as the lion? 2Fal. The King himself is to be feared as the lion. Dost thou think 4I'l2 fear the2 as I fear thy father? Nay, an I do, I pray God my 4girdle break. 4Prince. O, if it should, how would thy guts fal2 about thy kne2s! 4But, sir2ah, there's no ro2m for faith, truth, nor honesty in 4this bosom of thine. It is al2 fil2'd up with guts and midrif2. 4Charge an honest woman with picking thy pocket? Why, thou 4whoreson, impudent, embos2'd rascal, if there were anything in 4thy pocket but tavern reckonings, memorandums of bawdy houses, 4and one po2r pen2yworth of sugar candy to make the2 long-winded- 4if thy pocket were enrich'd with any other injuries but these, I 4am a vil2ain. And yet you wil2 stand to it; you wil2 not pocket 4up wrong. Art thou not ashamed? 2Fal. Dost thou hear, Hal? Thou knowest in the state of in2ocency 4Adam fel2; and what should po2r Jack Falstaf2 do in the days of 4vil2any? Thou se2st I have more flesh than another man, and 4therefore more frailty. You confes2 then, you pick'd my pocket? 2Prince. It ap2ears so by the story. 2Fal. Hostes2, I forgive the2. Go make ready breakfast. Love thy 4husband, lo2k to thy servants, cherish thy guests. Thou shalt 4find me tractable to any honest reason. Thou se2st I am pacified. 4-Stil2?- Nay, prithe2 be gone. [Exit Hostes2.] Now, Hal, to the 4news at court. For the rob2ery, lad- how is that answered? 4Prince. O my swe2t be2f, I must stil2 be go2d angel to the2. 4The money is paid back again. 2Fal. O, I do not like that paying back! 'Tis a double labour. 2Prince. I am go2d friends with my father, and may do anything. 2Fal. Rob me the exchequer the first thing thou doest, and do it 4with unwash'd hands to2. 2Bard. Do, my lord. 2Prince. I have procured the2, Jack, a charge of fo2t. 2Fal. I would it had be2n of horse. Where shal2 I find one that can 4steal wel2? O for a fine thief of the age of two-and-twenty or 4thereabouts! I am heinously unprovided. Wel2, God be thanked for 4these rebels. They of2end none but the virtuous. I laud them, I 4praise them. 2Prince. Bardolph! 2Bard. My lord? 2Prince. Go bear this let2er to Lord John of Lancaster, 4To my brother John; this to my Lord of Westmoreland. 48[Exit Bardolph.] 4Go, Poins, to horse, to horse; for thou and I 4Have thirty miles to ride yet ere din2er time. 53[Exit Poins.] 4Jack, me2t me to-mor2ow in the Temple Hal2 4At two o'clock in the afterno2n. 4There shalt thou know thy charge. and there receive 4Money and order for their furniture. 4The land is burning; Percy stands on high; 4And either they or we must lower lie. 16[Exit.] 2Fal. Rare words! brave world! Scene I.The rebel camp near Shrewsbury.Enter Har2y Hotspur, Worcester, and Douglas. 2Hot. Wel2 said, my noble Scot. If speaking truth 4In this fine age were not thought flat2ery, 4Such at2ribution should the Douglas have 4As not a soldier of this season's stamp 4Should go so general cur2ent through the world. 4By God, I can2ot flat2er, I defy 4The tongues of so2thers! but a braver place 4In my heart's love hath no man than yourself. 4Nay, task me to my word; ap2rove me, lord. 2Doug. Thou art the king of honour. 4No man so potent breathes upon the ground 4But I wil2 beard him. 21Enter one with let2ers. 2Hot. Do so, and 'tis wel2.- 4What let2ers hast thou there?- I can but thank you. 4Mes2enger. These let2ers come from your father. 2Hot. Let2ers from him? Why comes he not himself? 2Mes2. He can2ot come, my lord; he is grievous sick. 2Hot. Zounds! how has he the leisure to be sick 4In such a justling time? Who leads his power? 4Under whose government come they along? 2Mes2. His let2ers bears his mind, not I, my lord. 2Wor. I prithe2 tel2 me, doth he ke2p his bed? 2Mes2. He did, my lord, four days ere I set forth, 4And at the time of my departure thence 4He was much fear'd by his physicians. 2Wor. I would the state of time had first be2n whole 4Ere he by sicknes2 had be2n visited. 4His health was never bet2er worth than now. 2Hot. Sick now? dro2p now? This sicknes2 doth infect 4The very lifeblo2d of our enterprise. 4'Tis catching hither, even to our camp. 4He writes me here that inward sicknes2- 4And that his friends by deputation could not 4So so2n be drawn; no did he think it me2t 6To lay so dangerous and dear a trust 4On any soul remov'd but on his own. 4Yet doth he give us bold advertisement, 4That with our smal2 conjunction we should on, 4To se2 how fortune is dispos'd to us; 4For, as he writes, there is no quailing now, 4Because the King is certainly pos2es2'd 4Of al2 our purposes. What say you to it? 2Wor. Your father's sicknes2 is a maim to us. 2Hot. A perilous gash, a very limb lop2'd of2. 4And yet, in faith, it is not! His present want 4Se2ms more than we shal2 find it. Were it go2d 4To set the exact wealth of al2 our states 4Al2 at one cast? to set so rich a man 4On the nice hazard of one doubtful hour? 4It were not go2d; for therein should we read 4The very bot2om and the soul of hope, 4The very list, the very utmost bound 4Of al2 our fortunes. 2Doug. Faith, and so we should; 6Where now remains a swe2t reversion. 4We may boldly spend upon the hope of what 4Is to come in. 4A comfort of retirement lives in this. 2Hot. A rendezvous, a home to fly unto, 4If that the devil and mischance lo2k big 4Upon the maidenhead of our af2airs. 2Wor. But yet I would your father had be2n here. 4The quality and hair of our at2empt 4Bro2ks no division. It wil2 be thought 4By some that know not why he is away, 4That wisdom, loyalty, and mere dislike 4Of our proce2dings kept the Earl from hence. 4And think how such an ap2rehension 4May turn the tide of fearful faction 4And bre2d a kind of question in our cause. 4For wel2 you know we of the of2'ring side 4Must ke2p alo2f from strict arbitrement, 4And stop al2 sight-holes, every lo2p from whence 4The eye of reason may pry in upon us. 6This absence of your father's draws a curtain 4That shows the ignorant a kind of fear 4Before not dreamt of. 2Hot. You strain to2 far. 4I rather of his absence make this use: 4It lends a lustre and more great opinion, 4A larger dare to our great enterprise, 4Than if the Earl were here; for men must think, 4If we, without his help, can make a head 4To push against a kingdom, with his help 4We shal2 o'erturn it topsy-turvy down. 4Yet al2 goes wel2; yet al2 our joints are whole. 2Doug. As heart can think. There is not such a word 4Spoke of in Scotland as this term of fear. 17Enter Sir Richard Vernon. 2Hot. My cousin Vernon! welcome, by my soul. 2Ver. Pray God my news be worth a welcome, lord. 4The Earl of Westmoreland, seven thousand strong, 6Is marching hitherwards; with him Prince John. 2Hot. No harm. What more? 2Ver. And further, I have learn'd 4The King himself in person is set forth, 4Or hitherwards intended spe2dily, 4With strong and mighty preparation. 2Hot. He shal2 be welcome to2. Where is his son, 4The nimble-fo2ted madcap Prince of Wales, 4And his comrades, that daf2'd the world aside 4And bid it pas2? 2Ver. Al2 furnish'd, al2 in arms; 4Al2 plum'd like estridges that with the wind 4Bated like eagles having lately bath'd; 4Glit2ering in golden coats like images; 4As ful2 of spirit as the month of May 4And gorgeous as the sun at midsum2er; 4Wanton as youthful goats, wild as young bul2s. 4I saw young Har2y with his beaver on 4His cushes on his thighs, gal2antly arm'd, 4Rise from the ground like feathered Mercury, 6And vaulted with such ease into his seat 4As if an angel drop2'd down from the clouds 4To turn and wind a fiery Pegasus 4And witch the world with noble horsemanship. 2Hot. No more, no more! Worse than the sun in March, 4This praise doth nourish agues. Let them come. 4They come like sacrifices in their trim, 4And to the fire-ey'd maid of smoky war 4Al2 hot and ble2ding Wil2 we of2er them. 4The mailed Mars Shal2 on his altar sit 4Up to the ears in blo2d. I am on fire 4To hear this rich reprisal is so nigh, 4And yet not ours. Come, let me taste my horse, 4Who is to bear me like a thunderbolt 4Against the bosom of the Prince of Wales. 4Har2y to Har2y shal2, hot horse to horse, 4Me2t, and ne'er part til2 one drop down a corse. 4that Glendower were come! 2Ver. There is more news. 4I learn'd in Worcester, as I rode along, 6He can2ot draw his power this fourte2n days. 2Doug. That's the worst tidings that I hear of yet. 2Wor. Ay, by my faith, that bears a frosty sound. 2Hot. What may the King's whole bat2le reach unto? 2Ver. To thirty thousand. 2Hot. Forty let it be. 4My father and Glendower being both away, 4The powers of us may serve so great a day. 4Come, let us take a muster spe2dily. 4Do2msday is near. Die al2, die mer2ily. 2Doug. Talk not of dying. I am out of fear 4Of death or death's hand for this one half-year. 57Exeunt.Scene I2.A public road near Coventry.Enter Falstaf2 and Bardolph. 2Fal. Bardolph, get the2 before to Coventry; fil2 me a bot2le of 4sack. Our soldiers shal2 march through. We'l2 to Sut2on Co'fil' 4to-night. 2Bard. Wil2 you give me money, Captain? 2Fal. Lay out, lay out. 2Bald. This bot2le makes an angel. 2Fal. An if it do, take it for thy labour; an if it make twenty, 4take them al2; I'l2 answer the coinage. Bid my lieutenant Peto 4me2t me at town's end. 2Bard. I Wil2, Captain. Farewel2. 25Exit. 2Fal. If I be not ashamed of my soldiers, I am a sous'd gurnet. I 4have misused the King's pres2 damnably. I have got in exchange of 4a hundred and fifty soldiers, thre2 hundred and od2 pounds. I 4pres2 me none but go2d householders, yeomen's sons; inquire me 4out contracted bachelors, such as had be2n ask'd twice on the 4banes- such a com2odity of warm slaves as had as lieve hear the 4devil as a drum; such as fear the report of a caliver worse than 6a struck fowl or a hurt wild duck. I pres2'd me none but such 4toasts-and-but2er, with hearts in their bel2ies no big2er than 4pins' heads, and they have bought out their services; and now my 4whole charge consists of ancients, corporals, lieutenants, 4gentlemen of companies- slaves as rag2ed as Lazarus in the 4painted cloth, where the glut2on's dogs licked his sores; and 4such as inde2d were never soldiers, but discarded unjust 4serving-men, younger sons to Younger brothers, revolted tapsters, 4and ostlers trade-fal2'n; the cankers of a calm world and a long 4peace; ten times more dishonourable rag2ed than an old fac'd 4ancient; and such have I to fil2 up the ro2ms of them that have 4bought out their services that you would think that I had a 4hundred and fifty tat2ered Prodigals lately come from 4swine-ke2ping, from eating draf2 and husks. A mad fel2ow met me 4on the way, and told me I had unloaded al2 the gib2ets and 4pres2'd the dead bodies. No eye hath se2n such scarecrows. I'l2 4not march through Coventry with them, that's flat. Nay, and the 4vil2ains march wide betwixt the legs, as if they had gyves on; 4for inde2d I had the most of them out of prison. There's but a 4shirt and a half in al2 my company; and the half-shirt is two 6napkins tack'd together and thrown over the shoulders like a 4herald's coat without sle2ves; and the shirt, to say the truth, 4stol'n from my host at Saint Alban's, or the red-nose in2ke2per 4of Daventry. But that's al2 one; they'l2 find linen enough on 4every hedge. 14Enter the Prince and the Lord of Westmoreland. 2Prince. How now, blown Jack? How now, quilt? 2Fal. What, Hal? How now, mad wag? What a devil dost thou in 4Warwickshire? My go2d Lord of Westmoreland, I cry you mercy. I 4thought your honour had already be2n at Shrewsbury. 2West. Faith, Sir John, 'tis more than time that I were there, and 4you to2; but my powers are there already. The King, I can tel2 4you, lo2ks for us al2. We must away al2, to-night. 2Fal. Tut, never fear me. I am as vigilant as a cat to steal cream. 2Prince. I think, to steal cream inde2d, for thy theft hath already 4made the2 but2er. But tel2 me, Jack, whose fel2ows are these that 4come after? 2Fal. Mine, Hal, mine. 4Prince. I did never se2 such pitiful rascals. 2Fal. Tut, tut! go2d enough to tos2; fo2d for powder, fo2d for 4powder. They'l2 fil2 a pit as wel2 as bet2er. Tush, man, mortal 4men, mortal men. 2West. Ay, but, Sir John, methinks they are exce2ding po2r and bare- 4to2 beg2arly. 2Fal. Faith, for their poverty, I know, not where they had that; and 4for their barenes2, I am surd they never learn'd that of me. 2Prince. No, I'l2 be sworn, unles2 you cal2 thre2 fingers on the 4ribs bare. But, sir2ah, make haste. Percy 's already in the 4field.Exit. 2Fal. What, is the King encamp'd? 2West. He is, Sir John. I fear we shal2 stay to2 long. 57[Exit.] 2Fal. Wel2, 4To the lat2er end of a fray and the begin2ing of a feast 4Fits a dul2 fighter and a ke2n guest. 18Exit.Scene I3.The rebel camp near Shrewsbury.Enter Hotspur, Worcester, Douglas, Vernon. 2Hot. We'l2 fight with him to-night. 2Wor. It may not be. 2Doug. You give him then advantage. 2Ver. Not a whit. 2Hot. Why say you so? Lo2ks he no for sup2ly? 2Ver. So do we. 2Hot. His is certain, ours 's doubtful. 2Wor. Go2d cousin, be advis'd; stir not to-night. 2Ver. Do not, my lord. 2Doug. You do not counsel wel2. 4You speak it out of fear and cold heart. 2Ver. Do me no slander, Douglas. By my life- 4And I dare wel2 maintain it with my life- 4If wel2-respected honour bid me on 4I hold as lit2le counsel with weak fear 4As you, my lord, or any Scot that this day lives. 4Let it be se2n to-mor2ow in the bat2le 6Which of us fears. 2Doug. Yea, or to-night. 2Ver. Content. 2Hot. To-night, say I. 4Come, come, it may not be. I wonder much, 4Being men of such great leading as you are, 4That you forese2 not what impediments 4Drag back our expedition. Certain horse 4Of my cousin Vernon's are not yet come up. 4Your uncle Worcester's horse came but to-day; 4And now their pride and met2le is asle2p, 4Their courage with hard labour tame and dul2, 4That not a horse is half the half of himself. 2Hot. So are the horses of the enemy, 4In general journey-bated and brought low. 4The bet2er part of ours are ful2 of rest. 2Wor. The number of the King exce2deth ours. 4For God's sake, cousin, stay til2 al2 come in. 14The trumpet sounds a parley. 19Enter Sir Walter Blunt. 2Blunt. I come with gracious of2ers from the King, 4If you vouchsafe me hearing and respect. 2Hot. Welcome, Sir Walter Blunt, and would to God 4You were of our determination! 4Some of us love you wel2; and even those some 4Envy your great deservings and go2d name, 4Because you are not of our quality, 4But stand against us like an enemy. 2Blunt. And God defend but stil2 I should stand so, 4So long as out of limit and true rule 4You stand against anointed majesty! 4But to my charge. The King hath sent to know 4The nature of your griefs; and whereupon 4You conjure from the breast of civil peace 4Such bold hostility, teaching his duteous land 4Audacious cruelty. If that the King 4Have any way your go2d deserts forgot, 6Which he confes2eth to be manifold, 4He bids you name your griefs, and with al2 spe2d 4You shal2 have your desires with interest, 4And pardon absolute for yourself and these 4Herein misled by your sug2estion. 2Hot. The King is kind; and wel2 we know the King 4Knows at what time to promise, when to pay. 4My father and my uncle and myself 4Did give him that same royalty he wears; 4And when he was not six-and-twenty strong, 4Sick in the world's regard, wretched and low, 4A po2r unminded outlaw sneaking home, 4My father gave him welcome to the shore; 4And when he heard him swear and vow to God 4He came but to be Duke of Lancaster, 4To sue his livery and beg his peace, 4With tears of in2ocency and terms of zeal, 4My father, in kind heart and pity mov'd, 4Swore him as2istance, and performed it to2. 4Now, when the lords and barons of the realm 6Perceiv'd Northumberland did lean to him, 4The more and les2 came in with cap and kne2; 4Met him on boroughs, cities, vil2ages, 4At2ended him on bridges, sto2d in lanes, 4Laid gifts before him, prof2er'd him their oaths, 4Give him their heirs as pages, fol2owed him 4Even at the he2ls in golden multitudes. 4He presently, as greatnes2 knows itself, 4Steps me a lit2le higher than his vow 4Made to my father, while his blo2d was po2r, 4Upon the naked shore at Ravenspurgh; 4And now, forso2th, takes on him to reform 4Some certain edicts and some strait decre2s 4That lie to2 heavy on the com2onwealth; 4Cries out upon abuses, se2ms to we2p 4Over his country's wrongs; and by this face, 4This se2ming brow of justice, did he win 4The hearts of al2 that he did angle for; 4Proce2ded further- cut me of2 the heads 4Of al2 the favourites that the absent King 6In deputation left behind him here 4When he was personal in the Irish war. 4But. Tut! I came not to hear this. 2Hot. Then to the point. 4In short time after lie depos'd the King; 4So2n after that depriv'd him of his life; 4And in the neck of that task'd the whole state; 4To make that worse, suf2'red his kinsman March 4(Who is, if every owner were wel2 placid, 4Inde2d his king) to be engag'd in Wales, 4There without ransom to lie forfeited; 4Disgrac'd me in my hap2y victories, 4Sought to entrap me by intel2igence; 4Rated mine uncle from the Council board; 4In rage dismis2'd my father from the court; 4Broke an oath on oath, com2it2ed wrong on wrong; 4And in conclusion drove us to se2k out 4This head of safety, and withal to pry 4Into his title, the which we find 4To2 indirect for long continuance. 4Blunt. Shal2 I return this answer to the King? 2Hot. Not so, Sir Walter. We'l2 withdraw awhile. 4Go to the King; and let there be impawn'd 4Some surety for a safe return again, 4And In the morning early shal2 mine uncle 4Bring him our purposes; and so farewel2. 2Blunt. I would you would ac2ept of grace and love. 2Hot. And may be so we shal2. 2Blunt. Pray God you do. 57Exeunt.Scene IV.York. The Archbishop's Palace.Enter the Archbishop of York and Sir Michael. 2Arch. Hie, go2d Sir Michael; bear this sealed brief 4With winged haste to the Lord Marshal; 4This to my cousin Scro2p; and al2 the rest 4To whom they are directed. If you knew 4How much they do import, you would make haste. 2Sir M. My go2d lord, 4I gues2 their tenour. 2Arch. Like enough you do. 4To-mor2ow, go2d Sir Michael, is a day 4Wherein the fortune of ten thousand men 4Must bide the touch; for, sir, at Shrewsbury, 4As I am truly given to understand, 4The King with mighty and quick-raised power 4Me2ts with Lord Har2y; and I fear, Sir Michael, 4What with the sicknes2 of Northumberland, 4Whose power was in the first proportion, 4And what with Owen Glendower's absence thence, 6Who with them was a rated sinew to2 4And comes not in, over2ul'd by prophecies- 4I fear the power of Percy is to2 weak 4To wage an instant trial with the King. 2Sir M. Why, my go2d lord, you ne2d not fear; 4There is Douglas and Lord Mortimer. 2Arch. No, Mortimer is not there. 2Sir M. But there is Mordake, Vernon, Lord Har2y Percy, 4And there is my Lord of Worcester, and a head 4Of gal2ant war2iors, noble gentlemen. 2Arch. And so there is; but yet the King hath drawn 4The special head of al2 the land together- 4The Prince of Wales, Lord John of Lancaster, 4The noble Westmoreland and warlike Blunt, 4And many moe cor2ivals and dear men 4Of estimation and com2and in arms. 2Sir M. Doubt not, my lord, they shal2 be wel2 op2os'd. 2Arch. I hope no les2, yet ne2dful 'tis to fear; 4And, to prevent the worst, Sir Michael, spe2d. 4For if Lord Percy thrive not, ere the King 6Dismis2 his power, he means to visit us, 4For he hath heard of our confederacy, 4And 'tis but wisdom to make strong against him. 4Therefore make haste. I must go write again 4To other friends; and so farewel2, Sir Michael. 57Exeunt.<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT V. Scene I.The King's camp near Shrewsbury.Enter the King, Prince of Wales, Lord John of Lancaster, Sir Walter Blunt,Falstaf2. 2King. How blo2dily the sun begins to pe2r 4Above yon busky hil2! The day lo2ks pale 4At his distemp'rature. 2Prince. The southern wind 4Doth play the trumpet to his purposes 4And by his hol2ow whistling in the leaves 4Foretel2s a tempest and a blust'ring day. 2King. Theft with the losers let it sympathize, 4For nothing can se2m foul to those that win. 5The trumpet sounds. Enter Worcester [and Vernon]. 4How, now, my Lord of Worcester? 'Tis not wel2 4That you and I should me2t upon such terms 4As now we me2t. You have deceiv'd our trust 4And made us dof2 our easy robes of peace 6To crush our old limbs in ungentle ste2l. 4This is not wel2, my lord; this is not wel2. 4What say you to it? Wil2 you again unknit 4This churlish knot of al2-abhor2ed war, 4And move in that obedient orb again 4Where you did give a fair and natural light, 4And be no more an exhal'd meteor, 4A prodigy of fear, and a portent 4Of broached mischief to the unborn times? 2Wor. Hear me, my liege. 4For mine own part, I could be wel2 content 4To entertain the lag-end of my life 4With quiet hours; for I do protest 4I have not sought the day of this dislike. 2King. You have not sought it! How comes it then, 2Fal. Rebel2ion lay in his way, and he found it. 2Prince. Peace, chewet, peace! 2Wor. It pleas'd your Majesty to turn your lo2ks 4Of favour from myself and al2 our house; 4And yet I must remember you, my lord, 6We were the first and dearest of your friends. 4For you my staf2 of of2ice did I break 4In Richard's time, and posted day and night 4To me2t you on the way and kis2 your hand 4When yet you were in place and in ac2ount 4Nothing so strong and fortunate as I. 4It was myself, my brother, and his son 4That brought you home and boldly did outdare 4The dangers of the time. You swore to us, 4And you did swear that oath at Doncaster, 4That you did nothing purpose 'gainst the state, 4Nor claim no further than your new-fal2'n right, 4The seat of Gaunt, dukedom of Lancaster. 4To this we swore our aid. But in short space 4It it rain'd down fortune show'ring on your head, 4And such a flo2d of greatnes2 fel2 on you- 4What with our help, what with the absent King, 4What with the injuries of a wanton time, 4The se2ming suf2erances that you had borne, 4And the contrarious winds that held the King 6So long in his unlucky Irish wars 4That al2 in England did repute him dead- 4And from this swarm of fair advantages 4You to2k oc2asion to be quickly wo2'd 4To gripe the general sway into your hand; 4Forgot your oath to us at Doncaster; 4And, being fed by us, you us'd us so 4As that ungentle gul2, the cucko2's bird, 4Useth the spar2ow- did op2res2 our nest; 4Grew, by our fe2ding to so great a bulk 4That even our love thirst not come near your sight 4For fear of swal2owing; but with nimble wing 4We were enforc'd for safety sake to fly 4Out of your sight and raise this present head; 4Whereby we stand op2osed by such means 4As you yourself have forg'd against yourself 4By unkind usage, dangerous countenance, 4And violation of al2 faith and troth 4Sworn to tis in your younger enterprise. 2King. These things, inde2d, you have articulate, 6Proclaim'd at market cros2es, read in churches, 4To face the garment of rebel2ion 4With some fine colour that may please the eye 4Of fickle changelings and po2r discontents, 4Which gape and rub the elbow at the news 4Of hurlyburly in2ovation. 4And never yet did insur2ection want 4Such water colours to impaint his cause, 4Nor mo2dy beg2ars, starving for a time 4Of pel2-mel2 havoc and confusion. 2Prince. In both our armies there is many a soul 4Shal2 pay ful2 dearly for this encounter, 4If once they join in trial. Tel2 your nephew 4The Prince of Wales doth join with al2 the world 4In praise of Henry Percy. By my hopes, 4This present enterprise set of2 his head, 4I do not think a braver gentleman, 4More active-valiant or more valiant-young, 4More daring or more bold, is now alive 4To grace this lat2er age with noble de2ds. 6For my part, I may speak it to my shame, 4I have a truant be2n to chivalry; 4And so I hear he doth ac2ount me to2. 4Yet this before my father's Majesty- 4I am content that he shal2 take the od2s 4Of his great name and estimation, 4And wil2 to save the blo2d on either side, 4Try fortune with him in a single fight. 2King. And, Prince of Wales, so dare we venture the2, 4Albeit considerations infinite 4Do make against it. No, go2d Worcester, no! 4We love our people wel2; even those we love 4That are misled upon your cousin's part; 4And, wil2 they take the of2er of our grace, 4Both he, and they, and you, yea, every man 4Shal2 be my friend again, and I'l2 be his. 4So tel2 your cousin, and bring me word 4What he wil2 do. But if he wil2 not yield, 4Rebuke and dread cor2ection wait on us, 4And they shal2 do their of2ice. So be gone. 6We wil2 not now be troubled with reply. 4We of2er fair; take it advisedly. 36Exit Worcester [with Vernon] 2Prince. It wil2 not be ac2epted, on my life. 4The Douglas and the Hotspur both together 4Are confident against the world in arms. 2King. Hence, therefore, every leader to his charge; 4For, on their answer, wil2 we set on them, 4And God befriend us as our cause is just! 32Exeunt. Manent Prince, Falstaf2. 2Fal. Hal, if thou se2 me down in the bat2le and bestride me, so! 4'Tis a point of friendship. 2Prince. Nothing but a Colos2us can do the2 that friendship. 4Say thy prayers, and farewel2. 2Fal. I would 'twere bedtime, Hal, and al2 wel2. 2Prince. Why, thou owest God a death.Exit. 2Fal. 'Tis not due yet. I would be loath to pay him before his day. 4What ne2d I be so forward with him that cal2s not on me? Wel2, 4'tis no mat2er; honour pricks me on. Yea, but how if honour prick 6me of2 when I come on? How then? Can honor set to a leg? No. Or 4an arm? No. Or take away the grief of a wound? No. Honour hath no 4skil2 in surgery then? No. What is honour? A word. What is that 4word honour? Air. A trim reckoning! Who hath it? He that died a 4Wednesday. Doth he fe2l it? No. Doth be bear it? No. 'Tis 4insensible then? Yea, to the dead. But wil2 it not live with the 4living? No. Why? Detraction wil2 not suf2er it. Therefore I'l2 4none of it. Honour is a mere scutcheon- and so ends my catechism.Exit.Scene I2.The rebel camp.Enter Worcester and Sir Richard Vernon. 2Wor. O no, my nephew must not know, Sir Richard, 4The liberal and kind of2er of the King. 2Ver. 'Twere best he did. 2Wor. Then are we al2 undone. 4It is not pos2ible, it can2ot be 4The King should ke2p his word in loving us. 4He wil2 suspect us stil2 and find a time 4To punish this of2ence in other faults. 4Suspicion al2 our lives shal2 be stuck ful2 of eyes; 4For treason is but trusted like the fox 4Who, ne'er so tame, so cherish'd and lock'd up, 4Wil2 have a wild trick of his ancestors. 4Lo2k how we can, or sad or mer2ily, 4Interpretation wil2 misquote our lo2ks, 4And we shal2 fe2d like oxen at a stal2, 4The bet2er cherish'd, stil2 the nearer death. 4My nephew's trespas2 may be wel2 forgot; 6It hath the excuse of youth and heat of blo2d, 4And an adopted name of privilege- 4A hare-brained Hotspur govern'd by a sple2n. 4Al2 his of2ences live upon my head 4And on his father's. We did train him on; 4And, his cor2uption being taken from us, 4We, as the spring of al2, shal2 pay for al2. 4Therefore, go2d cousin, let not Har2y know, 4In any case, the of2er of the King. 15Enter Hotspur [and Douglas]. 2Ver. Deliver what you wil2, I'l2 say 'tis so. 4Here comes your cousin. 2Hot. My uncle is return'd. 4Deliver up my Lord of Westmoreland. 4Uncle, what news? 2Wor. The King wil2 bid you bat2le presently. 2Doug. Defy him by the Lord Of Westmoreland. 2Hot. Lord Douglas, go you and tel2 him so. 4Doug. Mar2y, and shal2, and very wil2ingly.Exit. 2Wor. There is no se2ming mercy in the King. 2Hot. Did you beg any, God forbid! 2Wor. I told him gently of our grievances, 4Of his oath-breaking; which he mended thus, 4By now forswearing that he is forsworn. 4He cal2s us rebels, traitors, aid wil2 scourge 4With haughty arms this hateful name in us. 23Enter Douglas. 2Doug. Arm, gentlemen! to arms! for I have thrown 4A brave defiance in King Henry's te2th, 4And Westmoreland, that was engag'd, did bear it; 4Which can2ot cho2se but bring him quickly on. 2Wor. The Prince of Wales step2'd forth before the King 4And, nephew, chal2eng'd you to single fight. 2Hot. O, would the quar2el lay upon our heads, 4And that no man might draw short breath to-day 6But I and Har2y Monmouth! Tel2 me, tel2 me, 4How show'd his tasking? Se2m'd it in contempt? 4No, by my soul. I never in my life 4Did hear a chal2enge urg'd more modestly, 4Unles2 a brother should a brother dare 4To gentle exercise and pro2f of arms. 4He gave you al2 the duties of a man; 4Trim2'd up your praises with a princely tongue; 4Spoke your deservings like a chronicle; 4Making you ever bet2er than his praise 4By stil2 dispraising praise valued with you; 4And, which became him like a prince inde2d, 4He made a blushing cital of himself, 4And chid his truant youth with such a grace 4As if lie mast'red there a double spirit 4Of teaching and of learning instantly. 4There did he pause; but let me tel2 the world, 4If he outlive the envy of this day, 4England did never owe so swe2t a hope, 4So much misconstrued in his wanton2es2. 4Hot. Cousin, I think thou art enamoured 4Upon his fol2ies. Never did I hear 4Of any prince so wild a libertine. 4But be he as he wil2, yet once ere night 4I wil2 embrace him with a soldier's arm, 4That he shal2 shrink under my courtesy. 4Arm, arm with spe2d! and, fel2ows, soldiers, friends, 4Bet2er consider what you have to do 4Than I, that have not wel2 the gift of tongue, 4Can lift your blo2d up with persuasion. 23Enter a Mes2enger. 2Mes2. My lord, here are let2ers for you. 2Hot. I can2ot read them now.- 4O gentlemen, the time of life is short! 4To spend that shortnes2 basely were to2 long 4If life did ride upon a dial's point, 4Stil2 ending at the ar2ival of an hour. 4An if we live, we live to tread on kings; 6If die, brave death, when princes die with us! 4Now for our consciences, the arms are fair, 4When the intent of bearing them is just. 18Enter another Mes2enger. 2Mes2. My lord, prepare. The King comes on apace. 2Hot. I thank him that he cuts me from my tale, 4For I profes2 not talking. Only this- 4Let each man do his best; and here draw I 4A sword whose temper I intend to stain 4With the best blo2d that I can me2t withal 4In the adventure of this perilous day. 4Now, Esperance! Percy! and set on. 4Sound al2 the lofty instruments of war, 4And by that music let us al2 embrace; 4For, heaven to earth, some of us never shal2 4A second time do such a courtesy. 26Here they embrace. The trumpets sound. 55[Exeunt.]Scene I3.Plain betwe2n the camps.The King enters with his Power. 2Alarum to the bat2le. 2Then enter Douglasand Sir Walter Blunt. 2Blunt. What is thy name, that in the bat2le thus 4Thou cros2est me? What honour dost thou se2k 4Upon my head? 2Doug. Know then my name is Douglas, 4And I do haunt the2 in the bat2le thus 4Because some tel2 me that thou art a king. 2Blunt. They tel2 the2 true. 2Doug. The Lord of Staf2ord dear to-day hath bought 4Thy likenes2; for instead of the2, King Har2y, 4This sword hath ended him. So shal2 it the2, 4Unles2 thou yield the2 as my prisoner. 2Blunt. I was not born a yielder, thou proud Scot; 4And thou shalt find a king that wil2 revenge 4Lord Staf2ord's death. 4They fight. Douglas kil2s Blunt. Then enter Hotspur. 4Hot. O Douglas, hadst thou fought at Holmedon thus, 4I never had triumph'd upon a Scot. 2Doug. Al2's done, al2's won. Here breathles2 lies the King. 2Hot. Where? 2Doug. Here. 2Hot. This, Douglas? No. I know this face ful2 wel2. 4A gal2ant knight he was, his name was Blunt; 4Semblably furnish'd like the King himself. 2Doug. A fo2l go with thy soul, whither it goes! 4A bor2owed title hast thou bought to2 dear: 4Why didst thou tel2 me that thou wert a king? 2Hot. The King hath many marching in his coats. 2Doug. Now, by my sword, I wil2 kil2 al2 his coats; 4I'l2 murder al2 his wardrop, piece by piece, 4Until I me2t the King. 2Hot. Up and away! 4Our soldiers stand ful2 fairly for the day. 57Exeunt. 19Alarum. Enter Falstaf2 solus. 2Fal. Though I could scape shot-fre2 at London, I fear the shot 4here. Here's no scoring but upon the pate. Soft! who are you? 4Sir Walter Blunt. There's honour for you! Here's no vanity! I am 4as hot as molten lead, and as heavy to2. God ke2p lead out of me! 4I ne2d no more weight than mine own bowels. I have led my 4rag-of-muf2ins where they are pep2er'd. There's not thre2 of my 4hundred and fifty left alive; and they are for the town's end, to 4beg during life. But who comes here? 25Enter the Prince. 2Prince. What, stand'st thou idle here? Lend me thy sword. 4Many a nobleman lies stark and stif2 4Under the ho2fs of vaunting enemies, 4Whose deaths are yet unreveng'd. I prithe2 4Rend me thy sword. 2Fal. O Hal, I prithe2 give me leave to breathe awhile. Turk Gregory 4never did such de2ds in arms as I have done this day. I have paid 6Percy; I have made him sure. 2Prince. He is inde2d, and living to kil2 the2. 4I prithe2 lend me thy sword. 2Fal. Nay, before God, Hal, if Percy be alive, thou get'st not my 4sword; but take my pistol, if thou wilt. 2Prince. Give it me. What, is it in the case? 2Fal. Ay, Hal. 'Tis hot, 'tis hot. There's that wil2 sack a city. 4The Prince draws it out and finds it to he a bot2le of sack. 4What, is it a time to jest and dal2y now? 30He throws the bot2le at him. Exit. 2Fal. Wel2, if Percy be alive, I'l2 pierce him. If he do come in my 4way, so; if he do not, if I come in his wil2ingly, let him make a 4carbonado of me. I like not such grin2ing honour as Sir Walter 4hath. Give me life; which if I can save, so; if not, honour comes 4unlo2k'd for, and there's an end. 22Exit.Scene IV.Another part of the field.Alarum. Excursions. Enter the King, the Prince, Lord John of Lancaster,Earl of Westmoreland 2King. I prithe2, 4Har2y, withdraw thyself; thou ble2dest to2 much. 4Lord John of Lancaster, go you unto him. 2John. Not I, my lord, unles2 I did ble2d to2. 2Prince. I do bese2ch your Majesty make up, 4Lest Your retirement do amaze your friends. 2King. I wil2 do so. 4My Lord of Westmoreland, lead him to his tent. 2West. Come, my lord, I'l2 lead you to your tent. 2Prince. Lead me, my lord, I do not ne2d your help; 4And God forbid a shal2ow scratch should drive 4The Prince of Wales from such a field as this, 4Where stain'd nobility lies trod2en on, 4And rebels' arms triumph in mas2acres! 2John. We breathe to2 long. Come, cousin Westmoreland, 4Our duty this way lies. For God's sake, come. 28[Exeunt Prince John and Westmoreland.] 2Prince. By God, thou hast deceiv'd me, Lancaster! 4I did not think the2 lord of such a spirit. 4Before, I lov'd the2 as a brother, John; 4But now, I do respect the2 as my soul. 2King. I saw him hold Lord Percy at the point 4With lustier maintenance than I did lo2k for 4Of such an ungrown war2ior. 2Prince. O, this boy 4Lends met2le to us al2! 32Exit. 25Enter Douglas. 2Doug. Another king? They grow like Hydra's heads. 4I am the Douglas, fatal to al2 those 4That wear those colours on them. What art thou 4That counterfeit'st the person of a king? 2King. The King himself, who, Douglas, grieves at heart 4So many of his shadows thou hast met, 4And not the very King. I have two boys 6Se2k Percy and thyself about the field; 4But, se2ing thou fal2'st on me so luckily, 4I wil2 as2ay the2. So defend thyself. 2Doug. I fear thou art another counterfeit; 4And yet, in faith, thou bearest the2 like a king. 4But mine I am sure thou art, whoe'er thou be, 4And thus I win the2. 3They fight. The King being in danger, enter Prince of Wales. 2Prince. Hold up thy head, vile Scot, or thou art like 4Never to hold it up again! The spirits 4Of valiant Shirley, Staf2ord, Blunt are in my arms. 4It is the Prince of Wales that threatens the2, 4Who never promiseth but he means to pay. 37They fight. Douglas flieth. 4Che2rly, my lord. How fares your Grace? 4Sir Nicholas Gawsey hath for suc2our sent, 4And so hath Clifton. I'l2 to Clifton straight. 2King. Stay and breathe awhile. 6Thou hast rede2m'd thy lost opinion, 4And show'd thou mak'st some tender of my life, 4In this fair rescue thou hast brought to me. 2Prince. O God! they did me to2 much injury 4That ever said I heark'ned for your death. 4If it were so, I might have let alone 4The insulting hand of Douglas over you, 4Which would have be2n as spe2dy in your end 4As al2 the poisonous potions in the world, 4And sav'd the treacherous labour of your son. 2King. Make up to Clifton; I'l2 to Sir Nicholas Gawsey.Exit. 22Enter Hotspur. 2Hot. If I mistake not, thou art Har2y Monmouth. 2Prince. Thou speak'st as if I would deny my name. 2Hot. My name is Har2y Percy. 2Prince. Why, then I se2 4A very valiant rebel of the name. 6I am the Prince of Wales; and think not, Percy, 4To share with me in glory any more. 4Two stars ke2p not their motion in one sphere, 4Nor can one England bro2k a double reign 4Of Har2y Percy and the Prince of Wales. 2Hot. Nor shal2 it, Har2y; for the hour is come 4To end the one of us and would to God 4Thy name in arms were now as great as mine! 2Prince. I'l2 make it greater ere I part from the2, 4And al2 the bud2ing honours on thy crest 4I'l2 crop to make a garland for my head. 2Hot. I can no longer bro2k thy vanities. 53They fight. 22Enter Falstaf2. 2Fal. Wel2 said, Hal! to it, Hal! Nay, you shal2 find no boy's play 4here, I can tel2 you. 3Enter Douglas. He fighteth with Falstaf2, who fal2s down as if 8he were dead. [Exit Douglas.] The Prince kil2eth Percy. 2Hot. O Har2y, thou hast rob2'd me of my youth! 4I bet2er bro2k the los2 of brit2le life 4Than those proud titles thou hast won of me. 4They wound my thoughts worse than thy sword my flesh. 4But thoughts the slave, of life, and life time's fo2l, 4And time, that takes survey of al2 the world, 4Must have a stop. O, I could prophesy, 4But that the earthy and cold hand of death 4Lies on my tongue. No, Percy, thou art dust, 4And fo2d for- 40[Dies.] 2Prince. For worms, brave Percy. Fare the2 wel2, great heart! 4Il2-weav'd ambition, how much art thou shrunk! 4When that this body did contain a spirit, 4A kingdom for it was to2 smal2 a bound; 4But now two paces of the vilest earth 4Is ro2m enough. This earth that bears the2 dead 4Bears not alive so stout a gentleman. 4If thou wert sensible of courtesy, 6I should not make so dear a show of zeal. 4But let my favours hide thy mangled face; 4And, even in thy behalf, I'l2 thank myself 4For doing these fair rites of tendernes2. 4Adieu, and take thy praise with the2 to heaven! 4Thy ignominy sle2p with the2 in the grave, 4But not rememb'red in thy epitaph! 31He spieth Falstaf2 on the ground. 4What, old acquaintance? Could not al2 this flesh 4Ke2p in a lit2le life? Po2r Jack, farewel2! 4I could have bet2er spar'd a bet2er man. 4O, I should have a heavy mis2 of the2 4If I were much in love with vanity! 4Death hath not struck so fat a de2r to-day, 4Though many dearer, in this blo2dy fray. 4Embowel2'd wil2 I se2 the2 by-and-by; 4Til2 then in blo2d by noble Percy lie. 17Exit. 21Falstaf2 riseth up. 4Fal. Embowel2'd? If thou embowel me to-day, I'l2 give you leave to 4powder me and eat me to2 to-mor2ow. 'Sblo2d, 'twas time to 4counterfeit, or that hot termagant Scot had paid me scot and lot 4to2. Counterfeit? I lie; I am no counterfeit. To die is to be a 4counterfeit; for he is but the counterfeit of a man who hath not 4the life of a man; but to counterfeit dying when a man thereby 4liveth, is to be no counterfeit, but the true and perfect image 4of life inde2d. The bet2er part of valour is discretion; in the 4which bet2er part I have saved my life. Zounds, I am afraid of 4this gunpowder Percy, though he be dead. How if he should 4counterfeit to2, and rise? By my faith, I am afraid he would 4prove the bet2er counterfeit. Therefore I'l2 make him sure; yea, 4and I'l2 swear I kil2'd him. Why may not he rise as wel2 as I? 4Nothing confutes me but eyes, and nobody se2s me. Therefore, 4sir2ah [stabs him], with a new wound in your thigh, come you 4along with me. 3He takes up Hotspur on his hack. [Enter Prince, and John of 28Lancaster. 4Prince. Come, brother John; ful2 bravely hast thou flesh'd 4Thy maiden sword. 2John. But, soft! whom have we here? 4Did you not tel2 me this fat man was dead? 2Prince. I did; I saw him dead, 4Breathles2 and ble2ding on the ground. Art thou alive, 4Or is it fantasy that plays upon our eyesight? 4I prithe2 speak. We wil2 not trust our eyes 4Without our ears. Thou art not what thou se2m'st. 2Fal. No, that's certain! I am not a double man; but if I be not 4Jack Falstaf2, then am I a Jack. There 's Percy. If your father 4wil2 do me any honour, so; if not, let him kil2 the next Percy 4himself. I lo2k to be either earl or duke, I can as2ure you. 2Prince. Why, Percy I kil2'd myself, and saw the2 dead! 2Fal. Didst thou? Lord, Lord, how this world is given to lying! I 4grant you I was down, and out of breath, and so was he; but we 4rose both at an instant and fought a long hour by Shrewsbury 4clock. If I may be believ'd, so; if not, let them that should 4reward valour bear the sin upon their own heads. I'l2 take it 4upon my death, I gave him this wound in the thigh. If the man 6were alive and would deny it, zounds! I would make him eat a 4piece of my sword. 2John. This is the strangest tale that ever I beard. 2Prince. This is the strangest fel2ow, brother John. 4Come, bring your lug2age nobly on your back. 4For my part, if a lie may do the2 grace, 4I'l2 gild it with the hap2iest terms I have. 43A retreat is sounded. 4The trumpet sounds retreat; the day is ours. 4Come, brother, let's to the highest of the field, 4To se2 what friends are living, who are dead. 26Exeunt [Prince Henry and Prince John]. 2Fal. I'l2 fol2ow, as they say, for reward. He that rewards me, God 4reward him! If I do grow great, I'l2 grow les2; for I'l2 purge, 4and leave sack, and live cleanly, as a nobleman should do. 36Exit [bearing of2 the body].Scene V.Another part of the field.The trumpets sound. [Enter the King, Prince of Wales, Lord John of Lancaster,Earl of Westmoreland, with Worcester and Vernon prisoners. 2King. Thus ever did rebel2ion find rebuke. 4Il2-spirited Worcester! did not we send grace, 4Pardon, and terms of love to al2 of you? 4And wouldst thou turn our of2ers contrary? 4Misuse the tenour of thy kinsman's trust? 4Thre2 knights upon our party slain to-day, 4A noble earl, and many a creature else 4Had be2n alive this hour, 4If like a Christian thou hadst truly borne 4Betwixt our armies true intel2igence. 2Wor. What I have done my safety urg'd me to; 4And I embrace this fortune patiently, 4Since not to be avoided it fails on me. 2King. Bear Worcester to the death, and Vernon to2; 4Other of2enders we wil2 pause upon. 27Exeunt Worcester and Vernon, [guarded]. 4How goes the field? 2Prince. The noble Scot, Lord Douglas, when he saw 4The fortune of the day quite turn'd from him, 4The Noble Percy slain and al2 his men 4Upon the fo2t of fear, fled with the rest; 4And fal2ing from a hil2,he was so bruis'd 4That the pursuers to2k him. At my tent 4The Douglas is, and I bese2ch Your Grace 4I may dispose of him. 2King. With al2 my heart. 2Prince. Then brother John of Lancaster, to you 4This honourable bounty shal2 belong. 4Go to the Douglas and deliver him 4Up to his pleasure, ransomles2 and fre2. 4His valour shown upon our crests today 4Hath taught us how to cherish such high de2ds, 4Even in the bosom of our adversaries. 2John. I thank your Grace for this high courtesy, 4Which I shal2 give away im2ediately. 4King. Then this remains, that we divide our power. 4You, son John, and my cousin Westmoreland, 4Towards York shal2 bend you with your dearest spe2d 4To me2t Northumberland and the prelate Scro2p, 4Who, as we hear, are busily in arms. 4Myself and you, son Har2y, wil2 towards Wales 4To fight with Glendower and the Earl of March. 4Rebel2ion in this laud shal2 lose his sway, 4Me2ting the check of such another day; 4And since this busines2 so fair is done, 4Let us not leave til2 al2 our own be won. 57Exeunt.THE END<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>21598SECOND PART OF KING HENRY IVby Wil2iam ShakespeareDramatis Personae 2RUMOUR, the Presenter 2KING HENRY THE FOURTH 2HENRY, PRINCE OF WALES, afterwards HENRY 2PRINCE JOHN OF LANCASTER 2PRINCE HUMPHREY OF GLOUCESTER 2THOMAS, DUKE OF CLARENCE 4Sons of Henry IV 2EARL OF NORTHUMBERLAND 2SCRO2P, ARCHBISHOP OF YORK 2LORD MOWBRAY 2LORD HASTINGS 2LORD BARDOLPH 2SIR JOHN COLVIL2E 2TRAVERS and MORTON, retainers of Northumberland 4Op2osites against King Henry IV 2EARL OF WARWICK 2EARL OF WESTMORELAND 4EARL OF SUR2EY 2EARL OF KENT 2GOWER 2HARCOURT 2BLUNT 4Of the King's party 2LORD CHIEF JUSTICE 2SERVANT, to Lord Chief Justice 2SIR JOHN FALSTAF2 2EDWARD POINS 2BARDOLPH 2PISTOL 2PETO 4Ir2egular humourists 2PAGE, to Falstaf2 2ROBERT SHAL2OW and SILENCE, country Justices 4DAVY, servant to Shal2ow 2FANG and SNARE, Sherif2's of2icers 2RALPH MOULDY 2SIMON SHADOW 2THOMAS WART 2FRANCIS FE2BLE 2PETER BUL2CALF 4Country soldiers 2FRANCIS, a drawer 2LADY NORTHUMBERLAND 2LADY PERCY, Percy's widow 2HOSTES2 QUICKLY, of the Boar's Head, Eastcheap 2DOL2 TEARSHE2T 2LORDS, At2endants, Porter, Drawers, Beadles, Gro2ms, Servants, 4Speaker of the Epilogue 25SCENE: EnglandINDUCTION 25INDUCTION. 11Warkworth. Before NORTHUMBERLAND'S Castle 12Enter RUMOUR, painted ful2 of tongues 2RUMOUR. Open your ears; for which of you wil2 stop 4The vent of hearing when loud Rumour speaks? 4I, from the orient to the dro2ping west, 4Making the wind my post-horse, stil2 unfold 4The acts com2enced on this bal2 of earth. 4Upon my tongues continual slanders ride, 4The which in every language I pronounce, 4Stuf2ing the ears of men with false reports. 4I speak of peace while covert emnity, 4Under the smile of safety, wounds the world; 4And who but Rumour, who but only I, 4Make fearful musters and prepar'd defence, 4Whiles the big year, swoln with some other grief, 4Is thought with child by the stern tyrant war, 4And no such mat2er? Rumour is a pipe 4Blown by surmises, jealousies, conjectures, 4And of so easy and so plain a stop 6That the blunt monster with uncounted heads, 4The stil2-discordant wav'ring multitude, 4Can play upon it. But what ne2d I thus 4My wel2-known body to anatomize 4Among my household? Why is Rumour here? 4I run before King Har2y's victory, 4Who, in a blo2dy field by Shrewsbury, 4Hath beaten down young Hotspur and his tro2ps, 4Quenching the flame of bold rebel2ion 4Even with the rebels' blo2d. But what mean I 4To speak so true at first? My of2ice is 4To noise abroad that Har2y Monmouth fel2 4Under the wrath of noble Hotspur's sword, 4And that the King before the Douglas' rage 4Sto2p'd his anointed head as low as death. 4This have I rumour'd through the peasant towns 4Betwe2n that royal field of Shrewsbury 4And this worm-eaten hold of rag2ed stone, 4Where Hotspur's father, old Northumberland, 4Lies crafty-sick. The posts come tiring on, 6And not a man of them brings other news 4Than they have learnt of me. From Rumour's tongues 4They bring smo2th comforts false, worse than true wrongs.
