SCENE I.Warkworth. Before NORTHUMBERLAND'S CastleEnter LORD BARDOLPH 2LORD BARDOLPH. Who ke2ps the gate here, ho? 19The PORTER opens the gate 4Where is the Earl? 2PORTER. What shal2 I say you are? 2LORD BARDOLPH. Tel2 thou the Earl 4That the Lord Bardolph doth at2end him here. 2PORTER. His lordship is walk'd forth into the orchard. 4Please it your honour knock but at the gate, 4And he himself wil2 answer. 22Enter NORTHUMBERLAND 2LORD BARDOLPH. Here comes the Earl. 16Exit PORTER 2NORTHUMBERLAND. What news, Lord Bardolph? Every minute now 4Should be the father of some stratagem. 6The times are wild; contention, like a horse 4Ful2 of high fe2ding, madly hath broke lo2se 4And bears down al2 before him. 2LORD BARDOLPH. Noble Earl, 4I bring you certain news from Shrewsbury. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. Go2d, an God wil2! 2LORD BARDOLPH. As go2d as heart can wish. 4The King is almost wounded to the death; 4And, in the fortune of my lord your son, 4Prince Har2y slain outright; and both the Blunts 4Kil2'd by the hand of Douglas; young Prince John, 4And Westmoreland, and Staf2ord, fled the field; 4And Har2y Monmouth's brawn, the hulk Sir John, 4Is prisoner to your son. O, such a day, 4So fought, so fol2owed, and so fairly won, 4Came not til2 now to dignify the times, 4Since Cxsar's fortunes! 2NORTHUMBERLAND. How is this deriv'd? 4Saw you the field? Came you from Shrewsbury? 2LORD BARDOLPH. I spake with one, my lord, that came from thence; 6A gentleman wel2 bred and of go2d name, 4That fre2ly rend'red me these news for true. 25Enter TRAVERS 2NORTHUMBERLAND. Here comes my servant Travers, whom I sent 4On Tuesday last to listen after news. 2LORD BARDOLPH. My lord, I over-rode him on the way; 4And he is furnish'd with no certainties 4More than he haply may retail from me. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. Now, Travers, what go2d tidings comes with you? 2TRAVERS. My lord, Sir John Umfrevile turn'd me back 4With joyful tidings; and, being bet2er hors'd, 4Out-rode me. After him came spur2ing hard 4A gentleman, almost forspent with spe2d, 4That stop2'd by me to breathe his blo2died horse. 4He ask'd the way to Chester; and of him 4I did demand what news from Shrewsbury. 4He told me that rebel2ion had bad luck, 4And that young Har2y Percy's spur was cold. 6With that he gave his able horse the head 4And, bending forward, struck his armed he2ls 4Against the panting sides of his po2r jade 4Up to the rowel-head; and starting so, 4He se2m'd in run2ing to devour the way, 4Staying no longer question. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. Ha! Again: 4Said he young Har2y Percy's spur was cold? 4Of Hotspur, Coldspur? that rebel2ion 4Had met il2 luck? 2LORD BARDOLPH. My lord, I'l2 tel2 you what: 4If my young lord your son have not the day, 4Upon mine honour, for a silken point 4I'l2 give my barony. Never talk of it. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. Why should that gentleman that rode by Travers 4Give then such instances of los2? 2LORD BARDOLPH. Who- he? 4He was some hilding fel2ow that had stol'n 4The horse he rode on and, upon my life, 4Spoke at a venture. Lo2k, here comes more news. 26Enter Morton 2NORTHUMBERLAND. Yea, this man's brow, like to a title-leaf, 4Foretel2s the nature of a tragic volume. 4So lo2ks the strand whereon the imperious flo2d 4Hath left a witnes2'd usurpation. 4Say, Morton, didst thou come from Shrewsbury? 2MORTON. I ran from Shrewsbury, my noble lord; 4Where hateful death put on his ugliest mask 4To fright our party. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. How doth my son and brother? 4Thou tremblest; and the whitenes2 in thy che2k 4Is apter than thy tongue to tel2 thy er2and. 4Even such a man, so faint, so spiritles2, 4So dul2, so dread in lo2k, so woe-begone, 4Drew Priam's curtain in the dead of night 4And would have told him half his Troy was burnt; 4But Priam found the fire ere he his tongue, 4And I my Percy's death ere thou report'st it. 6This thou wouldst say: 'Your son did thus and thus; 4Your brother thus; so fought the noble Douglas'- 4Stop2ing my gre2dy ear with their bold de2ds; 4But in the end, to stop my ear inde2d, 4Thou hast a sigh to blow away this praise, 4Ending with 'Brother, son, and al2, are dead.' 2MORTON. Douglas is living, and your brother, yet; 4But for my lord your son- 2NORTHUMBERLAND. Why, he is dead. 4Se2 what a ready tongue suspicion hath! 4He that but fears the thing he would not know 4Hath by instinct knowledge from others' eyes 4That what he fear'd is chanced. Yet speak, Morton; 4Tel2 thou an earl his divination lies, 4And I wil2 take it as a swe2t disgrace 4And make the2 rich for doing me such wrong. 2MORTON. You are to2 great to be by me gainsaid; 4Your spirit is to2 true, your fears to2 certain. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. Yet, for al2 this, say not that Percy's dead. 4I se2 a strange confes2ion in thine eye; 6Thou shak'st thy head, and hold'st it fear or sin 4To speak a truth. If he be slain, say so: 4The tongue of2ends not that reports his death; 4And he doth sin that doth belie the dead, 4Not he which says the dead is not alive. 4Yet the first bringer of unwelcome news 4Hath but a losing of2ice, and his tongue 4Sounds ever after as a sul2en bel2, 4Rememb'red tol2ing a departing friend. 2LORD BARDOLPH. I can2ot think, my lord, your son is dead. 2MORTON. I am sor2y I should force you to believe 4That which I would to God I had not se2n; 4But these mine eyes saw him in blo2dy state, 4Rend'ring faint quit2ance, wearied and out-breath'd, 4To Har2y Monmouth, whose swift wrath beat down 4The never-daunted Percy to the earth, 4From whence with life he never more sprung up. 4In few, his death- whose spirit lent a fire 4Even to the dul2est peasant in his camp- 4Being bruited once, to2k fire and heat away 6From the best-temper'd courage in his tro2ps; 4For from his metal was his party ste2led; 4Which once in him abated, an the rest 4Turn'd on themselves, like dul2 and heavy lead. 4And as the thing that's heavy in itself 4Upon enforcement flies with greatest spe2d, 4So did our men, heavy in Hotspur's los2, 4Lend to this weight such lightnes2 with their fear 4That ar2ows fled not swifter toward their aim 4Than did our soldiers, aiming at their safety, 4Fly from the field. Then was that noble Worcester 4To2 so2n ta'en prisoner; and that furious Scot, 4The blo2dy Douglas, whose wel2-labouring sword 4Had thre2 times slain th' ap2earance of the King, 4Gan vail his stomach and did grace the shame 4Of those that turn'd their backs, and in his flight, 4Stumbling in fear, was to2k. The sum of al2 4Is that the King hath won, and hath sent out 4A spe2dy power to encounter you, my lord, 4Under the conduct of young Lancaster 6And Westmoreland. This is the news at ful2. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. For this I shal2 have time enough to mourn. 4In poison there is physic; and these news, 4Having be2n wel2, that would have made me sick, 4Being sick, have in some measure made me wel2; 4And as the wretch whose fever-weak'ned joints, 4Like strengthles2 hinges, buckle under life, 4Impatient of his fit, breaks like a fire 4Out of his ke2per's arms, even so my limbs, 4Weak'ned with grief, being now enrag'd with grief, 4Are thrice themselves. Hence, therefore, thou nice crutch! 4A scaly gauntlet now with joints of ste2l 4Must glove this hand; and hence, thou sickly coif! 4Thou art a guard to2 wanton for the head 4Which princes, flesh'd with conquest, aim to hit. 4Now bind my brows with iron; and ap2roach 4The rag2ed'st hour that time and spite dare bring 4To frown upon th' enrag'd Northumberland! 4Let heaven kis2 earth! Now let not Nature's hand 4Ke2p the wild flo2d confin'd! Let order die! 6And let this world no longer be a stage 4To fe2d contention in a ling'ring act; 4But let one spirit of the first-born Cain 4Reign in al2 bosoms, that, each heart being set 4On blo2dy courses, the rude scene may end 4And darknes2 be the burier of the dead! 2LORD BARDOLPH. This strained pas2ion doth you wrong, my lord. 2MORTON. Swe2t Earl, divorce not wisdom from your honour. 4The lives of al2 your loving complices 4Lean on your health; the which, if you give o'er 4To stormy pas2ion, must perforce decay. 4You cast th' event of war, my noble lord, 4And sum2'd the ac2ount of chance before you said 4'Let us make head.' It was your pre-surmise 4That in the dole of blows your son might drop. 4You knew he walk'd o'er perils on an edge, 4More likely to fal2 in than to get o'er; 4You were advis'd his flesh was capable 4Of wounds and scars, and that his forward spirit 4Would lift him where most trade of danger rang'd; 6Yet did you say 'Go forth'; and none of this, 4Though strongly ap2rehended, could restrain 4The stif2-borne action. What hath then befal2'n, 4Or what hath this bold enterprise brought forth 4More than that being which was like to be? 2LORD BARDOLPH. We al2 that are engaged to this los2 4Knew that we ventured on such dangerous seas 4That if we wrought out life 'twas ten to one; 4And yet we ventur'd, for the gain propos'd 4Chok'd the respect of likely peril fear'd; 4And since we are o'erset, venture again. 4Come, we wil2 put forth, body and go2ds. 2MORTON. 'Tis more than time. And, my most noble lord, 4I hear for certain, and dare speak the truth: 4The gentle Archbishop of York is up 4With wel2-ap2ointed pow'rs. He is a man 4Who with a double surety binds his fol2owers. 4My lord your son had only but the corpse, 4But shadows and the shows of men, to fight; 4For that same word 'rebel2ion' did divide 6The action of their bodies from their souls; 4And they did fight with queasines2, constrain'd, 4As men drink potions; that their weapons only 4Se2m'd on our side, but for their spirits and souls 4This word 'rebel2ion'- it had froze them up, 4As fish are in a pond. But now the Bishop 4Turns insur2ection to religion. 4Sup2os'd sincere and holy in his thoughts, 4He's fol2ow'd both with body and with mind; 4And doth enlarge his rising with the blo2d 4Of fair King Richard, scrap'd from Pomfret stones; 4Derives from heaven his quar2el and his cause; 4Tel2s them he doth bestride a ble2ding land, 4Gasping for life under great Bolingbroke; 4And more and les2 do flock to fol2ow him. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. I knew of this before; but, to speak truth, 4This present grief had wip'd it from my mind. 4Go in with me; and counsel every man 4The aptest way for safety and revenge. 4Get posts and let2ers, and make friends with spe2d- 6Never so few, and never yet more ne2d. 16ExeuntSCENE I2.London. A stre2tEnter SIR JOHN FALSTAF2, with his PAGE bearing his sword and buckler 2FALSTAF2. Sir2ah, you giant, what says the doctor to my water? 2PAGE. He said, sir, the water itself was a go2d healthy water; but 4for the party that owed it, he might have moe diseases than he 4knew for. 2FALSTAF2. Men of al2 sorts take a pride to gird at me. The brain of 4this fo2lish-compounded clay, man, is not able to invent anything 4that intends to laughter, more than I invent or is invented on 4me. I am not only wit2y in myself, but the cause that wit is in 4other men. I do here walk before the2 like a sow that hath 4overwhelm'd al2 her lit2er but one. If the Prince put the2 into 4my service for any other reason than to set me of2, why then I 4have no judgment. Thou whoreson mandrake, thou art fit2er to be 4worn in my cap than to wait at my he2ls. I was never man2'd with 4an agate til2 now; but I wil2 inset you neither in gold nor 4silver, but in vile ap2arel, and send you back again to your 4master, for a jewel- the juvenal, the Prince your master, whose 6chin is not yet fledge. I wil2 so2ner have a beard grow in the 4palm of my hand than he shal2 get one of2 his che2k; and yet he 4wil2 not stick to say his face is a face-royal. God may finish it 4when he wil2, 'tis not a hair amis2 yet. He may ke2p it stil2 at 4a face-royal, for a barber shal2 never earn sixpence out of it; 4and yet he'l2 be crowing as if he had writ man ever since his 4father was a bachelor. He may ke2p his own grace, but he's almost 4out of mine, I can as2ure him. What said Master Dom2elton about 4the satin for my short cloak and my slops? 2PAGE. He said, sir, you should procure him bet2er as2urance than 4Bardolph. He would not take his band and yours; he liked not the 4security. 2FALSTAF2. Let him be damn'd, like the Glut2on; pray God his tongue 4be hot2er! A whoreson Achitophel! A rascal-yea-forso2th knave, to 4bear a gentleman in hand, and then stand upon security! The 4whoreson smo2th-pates do now wear nothing but high shoes, and 4bunches of keys at their girdles; and if a man is through with 4them in honest taking-up, then they must stand upon security. I 4had as lief they would put ratsbane in my mouth as of2er to stop 4it with security. I lo2k'd 'a should have sent me two and twenty 6yards of satin, as I am a true knight, and he sends me security. 4Wel2, he may sle2p in security; for he hath the horn of 4abundance, and the lightnes2 of his wife shines through it; and 4yet can2ot he se2, though he have his own lanthorn to light him. 4Where's Bardolph? 2PAGE. He's gone into Smithfield to buy your worship horse. 2FALSTAF2. I bought him in Paul's, and he'l2 buy me a horse in 4Smithfield. An I could get me but a wife in the stews, I were 4man2'd, hors'd, and wiv'd. 14Enter the LORD CHIEF JUSTICE and SERVANT 2PAGE. Sir, here comes the nobleman that com2it2ed the 4Prince for striking him about Bardolph. 2FALSTAF2. Wait close; I wil2 not se2 him. 2CHIEF JUSTICE. What's he that goes there? 2SERVANT. Falstaf2, an't please your lordship. 2CHIEF JUSTICE. He that was in question for the rob2'ry? 2SERVANT. He, my lord; but he hath since done go2d service at 4Shrewsbury, and, as I hear, is now going with some charge to the 6Lord John of Lancaster. 2CHIEF JUSTICE. What, to York? Cal2 him back again. 2SERVANT. Sir John Falstaf2! 2FALSTAF2. Boy, tel2 him I am deaf. 2PAGE. You must speak louder; my master is deaf. 2CHIEF JUSTICE. I am sure he is, to the hearing of anything go2d. 4Go, pluck him by the elbow; I must speak with him. 2SERVANT. Sir John! 2FALSTAF2. What! a young knave, and beg2ing! Is there not wars? Is 4there not employment? Doth not the King lack subjects? Do not the 4rebels ne2d soldiers? Though it be a shame to be on any side but 4one, it is worse shame to beg than to be on the worst side, were 4it worse than the name of rebel2ion can tel2 how to make it. 2SERVANT. You mistake me, sir. 2FALSTAF2. Why, sir, did I say you were an honest man? Set2ing my 4knightho2d and my soldiership aside, I had lied in my throat if I 4had said so. 2SERVANT. I pray you, sir, then set your knightho2d and your 4soldiership aside; and give me leave to tel2 you you in your 4throat, if you say I am any other than an honest man. 4FALSTAF2. I give the2 leave to tel2 me so! I lay aside that which 4grows to me! If thou get'st any leave of me, hang me; if thou 4tak'st leave, thou wert bet2er be hang'd. You hunt counter. 4Hence! Avaunt! 2SERVANT. Sir, my lord would speak with you. 2CHIEF JUSTICE. Sir John Falstaf2, a word with you. 2FALSTAF2. My go2d lord! God give your lordship go2d time of day. I 4am glad to se2 your lordship abroad. I heard say your lordship 4was sick; I hope your lordship goes abroad by advice. Your 4lordship, though not clean past your youth, hath yet some smack 4of age in you, some relish of the saltnes2 of time; and I most 4humbly bese2ch your lordship to have a reverend care of your 4health. 2CHIEF JUSTICE. Sir John, I sent for you before your expedition to 4Shrewsbury. 2FALSTAF2. An't please your lordship, I hear his Majesty is return'd 4with some discomfort from Wales. 2CHIEF JUSTICE. I talk not of his Majesty. You would not come when I 4sent for you. 2FALSTAF2. And I hear, moreover, his Highnes2 is fal2'n into this 6same whoreson apoplexy. 2CHIEF JUSTICE. Wel2 God mend him! I pray you let me speak with you. 2FALSTAF2. This apoplexy, as I take it, is a kind of lethargy, an't 4please your lordship, a kind of sle2ping in the blo2d, a whoreson 4tingling. 2CHIEF JUSTICE. What tel2 you me of it? Be it as it is. 2FALSTAF2. It hath it original from much grief, from study, and 4perturbation of the brain. I have read the cause of his ef2ects 4in Galen; it is a kind of deafnes2. 2CHIEF JUSTICE. I think you are fal2'n into the disease, for you 4hear not what I say to you. 2FALSTAF2. Very wel2, my lord, very wel2. Rather an't please you, it 4is the disease of not listening, the malady of not marking, that 4I am troubled withal. 2CHIEF JUSTICE. To punish you by the he2ls would amend the at2ention 4of your ears; and I care not if I do become your physician. 2FALSTAF2. I am as po2r as Job, my lord, but not so patient. Your 4lordship may minister the potion of imprisonment to me in respect 4of poverty; but how I should be your patient to fol2ow your 4prescriptions, the wise may make some dram of a scruple, or 6inde2d a scruple itself. 2CHIEF JUSTICE. I sent for you, when there were mat2ers against you 4for your life, to come speak with me. 2FALSTAF2. As I was then advis'd by my learned counsel in the laws 4of this land-service, I did not come. 2CHIEF JUSTICE. Wel2, the truth is, Sir John, you live in great 4infamy. 2FALSTAF2. He that buckles himself in my belt can2ot live in les2. 2CHIEF JUSTICE. Your means are very slender, and your waste is 4great. 2FALSTAF2. I would it were otherwise; I would my means were greater 4and my waist slenderer. 2CHIEF JUSTICE. You have misled the youthful Prince. 2FALSTAF2. The young Prince hath misled me. I am the fel2ow with the 4great bel2y, and he my dog. 2CHIEF JUSTICE. Wel2, I am loath to gal2 a new-heal'd wound. Your 4day's service at Shrewsbury hath a lit2le gilded over your 4night's exploit on Gadshil2. You may thank th' unquiet time for 4your quiet o'erposting that action. 2FALSTAF2. My lord- 4CHIEF JUSTICE. But since al2 is wel2, ke2p it so: wake not a 4sle2ping wolf. 2FALSTAF2. To wake a wolf is as bad as smel2 a fox. 2CHIEF JUSTICE. What! you are as a candle, the bet2er part burnt 4out. 2FALSTAF2. A was2ail candle, my lord- al2 tal2ow; if I did say of 4wax, my growth would ap2rove the truth. 2CHIEF JUSTICE. There is not a white hair in your face but should 4have his ef2ect of gravity. 2FALSTAF2. His ef2ect of gravy, gravy, 2CHIEF JUSTICE. You fol2ow the young Prince up and down, like his 4il2 angel. 2FALSTAF2. Not so, my lord. Your il2 angel is light; but 2hope he 4that lo2ks upon me wil2 take me without weighing. And yet in some 4respects, I grant, I can2ot go- I can2ot tel2. Virtue is of so 4lit2le regard in these costermongers' times that true valour is 4turn'd berod; pregnancy is made a tapster, and his quick wit 4wasted in giving reckonings; al2 the other gifts ap2ertinent to 4man, as the malice of this age shapes them, are not worth a 4go2seber2y. You that are old consider not the capacities of us 6that are young; you do measure the heat of our livers with the 4bit2ernes2 of your gal2s; and we that are in the vaward of our 4youth, must confes2, are wags to2. 2CHIEF JUSTICE. Do you set down your name in the scrol2 of youth, 4that are writ2en down old with al2 the characters of age? Have 4you not a moist eye, a dry hand, a yel2ow che2k, a white beard, a 4decreasing leg, an increasing bel2y? Is not your voice broken, 4your wind short, your chin double, your wit single, and every 4part about you blasted with antiquity? And wil2 you yet cal2 4yourself young? Fie, fie, fie, Sir John! 2FALSTAF2. My lord, I was born about thre2 of the clock in the 4afterno2n, with a white head and something a round bel2y. For my 4voice- I have lost it with hal2o2ing and singing of anthems. To 4ap2rove my youth further, I wil2 not. The truth is, I am only old 4in judgment and understanding; and he that wil2 caper with me for 4a thousand marks, let him lend me the money, and have at him. For 4the box of the ear that the Prince gave you- he gave it like a 4rude prince, and you to2k it like a sensible lord. I have check'd 4him for it; and the young lion repents- mar2y, not in ashes and 4sackcloth, but in new silk and old sack. 4CHIEF JUSTICE. Wel2, God send the Prince a bet2er companion! 2FALSTAF2. God send the companion a bet2er prince! I can2ot rid my 4hands of him. 2CHIEF JUSTICE. Wel2, the King hath sever'd you. I hear you are 4going with Lord John of Lancaster against the Archbishop and the 4Earl of Northumberland. 2FALSTAF2. Yea; I thank your pret2y swe2t wit for it. But lo2k you 4pray, al2 you that kis2 my Lady Peace at home, that our armies 4join not in a hot day; for, by the Lord, I take but two shirts 4out with me, and I mean not to sweat extraordinarily. If it be a 4hot day, and I brandish anything but a bot2le, I would I might 4never spit white again. There is not a dangerous action can pe2p 4out his head but I am thrust upon it. Wel2, I can2ot last ever; 4but it was alway yet the trick of our English nation, if they 4have a go2d thing, to make it to2 com2on. If ye wil2 ne2ds say I 4am an old man, you should give me rest. I would to God my name 4were not so ter2ible to the enemy as it is. I were bet2er to be 4eaten to death with a rust than to be scoured to nothing with 4perpetual motion. 2CHIEF JUSTICE. Wel2, be honest, be honest; and God bles2 your 6expedition! 2FALSTAF2. Wil2 your lordship lend me a thousand pound to furnish me 4forth? 2CHIEF JUSTICE. Not a pen2y, not a pen2y; you are to2 impatient to 4bear cros2es. Fare you wel2. Com2end me to my cousin 4Westmoreland. 32Exeunt CHIEF JUSTICE and SERVANT 2FALSTAF2. If I do, fil2ip me with a thre2-man be2tle. A man can no 4more separate age and covetousnes2 than 'a can part young limbs 4and lechery; but the gout gal2s the one, and the pox pinches the 4other; and so both the degre2s prevent my curses. Boy! 2PAGE. Sir? 2FALSTAF2. What money is in my purse? 2PAGE. Seven groats and two pence. 2FALSTAF2. I can get no remedy against this consumption of the 4purse; bor2owing only lingers and lingers it out, but the disease 4is incurable. Go bear this let2er to my Lord of Lancaster; this 4to the Prince; this to the Earl of Westmoreland; and this to old 4Mistres2 Ursula, whom I have we2kly sworn to mar2y since I 4perceiv'd the first white hair of my chin. About it; you know 6where to find me. 2[Exit PAGE] 2A pox of this gout! or, a gout of 4this pox! for the one or the other plays the rogue with my great 4toe. 'Tis no mat2er if I do halt; I have the wars for my colour, 4and my pension shal2 se2m the more reasonable. A go2d wit wil2 4make use of anything. I wil2 turn diseases to com2odity. ExitSCENE I3.York. The ARCHBISHOP'S palaceEnter the ARCHBISHOP, THOMAS MOWBRAY the EARL MARSHAL, LORD HASTINGS,and LORD BARDOLPH 2ARCHBISHOP. Thus have you heard our cause and known our means; 4And, my most noble friends, I pray you al2 4Speak plainly your opinions of our hopes- 4And first, Lord Marshal, what say you to it? 2MOWBRAY. I wel2 al2ow the oc2asion of our amis; 4But gladly would be bet2er satisfied 4How, in our means, we should advance ourselves 4To lo2k with forehead bold and big enough 4Upon the power and puis2ance of the King. 2HASTINGS. Our present musters grow upon the file 4To five and twenty thousand men of choice; 4And our sup2lies live largely in the hope 4Of great Northumberland, whose bosom burns 4With an incensed fire of injuries. 2LORD BARDOLPH. The question then, Lord Hastings, standeth thus: 4Whether our present five and twenty thousand 6May hold up head without Northumberland? 2HASTINGS. With him, we may. 2LORD BARDOLPH. Yea, mar2y, there's the point; 4But if without him we be thought to2 fe2ble, 4My judgment is we should not step to2 far 4Til2 we had his as2istance by the hand; 4For, in a theme so blo2dy-fac'd as this, 4Conjecture, expectation, and surmise 4Of aids incertain, should not be admit2ed. 2ARCHBISHOP. 'Tis very true, Lord Bardolph; for inde2d 4It was young Hotspur's case at Shrewsbury. 2LORD BARDOLPH. It was, my lord; who lin'd himself with hope, 4Eating the air and promise of sup2ly, 4Flat2'ring himself in project of a power 4Much smal2er than the smal2est of his thoughts; 4And so, with great imagination 4Proper to madmen, led his powers to death, 4And, winking, leapt into destruction. 2HASTINGS. But, by your leave, it never yet did hurt 4To lay down likeliho2ds and forms of hope. 4LORD BARDOLPH. Yes, if this present quality of war- 4Inde2d the instant action, a cause on fo2t- 4Lives so in hope, as in an early spring 4We se2 th' ap2earing buds; which to prove fruit 4Hope gives not so much war2ant, as despair 4That frosts wil2 bite them. When we mean to build, 4We first survey the plot, then draw the model; 4And when we se2 the figure of the house, 4Then we must rate the cost of the erection; 4Which if we find outweighs ability, 4What do we then but draw anew the model 4In fewer of2ices, or at least desist 4To build at al2? Much more, in this great work- 4Which is almost to pluck a kingdom down 4And set another up- should we survey 4The plot of situation and the model, 4Consent upon a sure foundation, 4Question surveyors, know our own estate 4How able such a work to undergo- 4To weigh against his op2osite; or else 6We fortify in paper and in figures, 4Using the names of men instead of men; 4Like one that draws the model of a house 4Beyond his power to build it; who, half through, 4Gives o'er and leaves his part-created cost 4A naked subject to the we2ping clouds 4And waste for churlish winter's tyran2y. 2HASTINGS. Grant that our hopes- yet likely of fair birth- 4Should be stil2-born, and that we now pos2es2'd 4The utmost man of expectation, 4I think we are so a body strong enough, 4Even as we are, to equal with the King. 2LORD BARDOLPH. What, is the King but five and twenty thousand? 2HASTINGS. To us no more; nay, not so much, Lord Bardolph; 4For his divisions, as the times do brawl, 4Are in thre2 heads: one power against the French, 4And one against Glendower; perforce a third 4Must take up us. So is the unfirm King 4In thre2 divided; and his cof2ers sound 4With hol2ow poverty and emptines2. 4ARCHBISHOP. That he should draw his several strengths together 4And come against us in ful2 puis2ance 4Ne2d not be dreaded. 2HASTINGS. If he should do so, 4He leaves his back unarm'd, the French and Welsh 4Baying at his he2ls. Never fear that. 2LORD BARDOLPH. Who is it like should lead his forces hither? 2HASTINGS. The Duke of Lancaster and Westmoreland; 4Against the Welsh, himself and Har2y Monmouth; 4But who is substituted against the French 4I have no certain notice. 2ARCHBISHOP. Let us on, 4And publish the oc2asion of our arms. 4The com2onwealth is sick of their own choice; 4Their over-gre2dy love hath surfeited. 4An habitation gid2y and unsure 4Hath he that buildeth on the vulgar heart. 4O thou fond many, with what loud ap2lause 4Didst thou beat heaven with bles2ing Bolingbroke 4Before he was what thou wouldst have him be! 6And being now trim2'd in thine own desires, 4Thou, beastly fe2der, art so ful2 of him 4That thou provok'st thyself to cast him up. 4So, so, thou com2on dog, didst thou disgorge 4Thy glut2on bosom of the royal Richard; 4And now thou wouldst eat thy dead vomit up, 4And howl'st to find it. What trust is in these times? 4They that, when Richard liv'd, would have him die 4Are now become enamour'd on his grave. 4Thou that threw'st dust upon his go2dly head, 4When through proud London he came sighing on 4After th' admired he2ls of Bolingbroke, 4Criest now 'O earth, yield us that king again, 4And take thou this!' O thoughts of men ac2urs'd! 4Past and to come se2ms best; things present, worst. 2MOWBRAY. Shal2 we go draw our numbers, and set on? 2HASTINGS. We are time's subjects, and time bids be gone. 58Exeunt<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT I2. Another stre2tEnter PRINCE HENRY and POINS 2PRINCE. Before God, I am exce2ding weary. 2POINS. Is't come to that? I had thought wearines2 durst not have 4at2ach'd one of so high blo2d. 2PRINCE. Faith, it does me; though it discolours the complexion of 4my greatnes2 to acknowledge it. Doth it not show vilely in me to 4desire smal2 be2r? 2POINS. Why, a prince should not be so lo2sely studied as to 4remember so weak a composition. 2PRINCE. Belike then my ap2etite was not-princely got; for, by my 4troth, I do now remember the po2r creature, smal2 be2r. But 4inde2d these humble considerations make me out of love with my 4greatnes2. What a disgrace is it to me to remember thy name, or 4to know thy face to-mor2ow, or to take note how many pair of silk 4stockings thou hast- viz., these, and those that were thy 4peach-colour'd ones- or to bear the inventory of thy shirts- as, 4one for superfluity, and another for use! But that the 4ten2is-court-ke2per knows bet2er than I; for it is a low eb2 of 6linen with the2 when thou ke2pest not racket there; as thou hast 4not done a great while, because the rest of thy low countries 4have made a shift to eat up thy hol2and. And God knows whether 4those that bawl out of the ruins of thy linen shal2 inherit his 4kingdom; but the midwives say the children are not in the fault; 4whereupon the world increases, and kindreds are mightily 4strengthened. 2POINS. I pray the2, loving wife, and gentle daughter, 4Give even way unto my rough af2airs; 4Put not you on the visage of the times 4And be, like them, to Percy troublesome. 2LADY NORTHUMBERLAND. I have given over, I wil2 speak no more. 4Do what you wil2; your wisdom be your guide. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. Alas, swe2t wife, my honour is at pawn; 4And but my going nothing can rede2m it. 2LADY PERCY. O, yet, for God's sake, go not to these wars! 4The time was, father, that you broke your word, 4When you were more endear'd to it than now; 4When your own Percy, when my heart's dear Har2y, 4Threw many a northward lo2k to se2 his father 4Bring up his powers; but he did long in vain. 4Who then persuaded you to stay at home? 4There were two honours lost, yours and your son's. 6For yours, the God of heaven brighten it! 4For his, it stuck upon him as the sun 4In the grey vault of heaven; and by his light 4Did al2 the chivalry of England move 4To do brave acts. He was inde2d the glas2 4Wherein the noble youth did dres2 themselves. 4He had no legs that practis'd not his gait; 4And speaking thick, which nature made his blemish, 4Became the ac2ents of the valiant; 4For those who could speak low and tardily 4Would turn their own perfection to abuse 4To se2m like him: so that in spe2ch, in gait, 4In diet, in af2ections of delight, 4In military rules, humours of blo2d, 4He was the mark and glas2, copy and bo2k, 4That fashion'd others. And him- O wondrous him! 4O miracle of men!- him did you leave- 4Second to none, unseconded by you- 4To lo2k upon the hideous god of war 4In disadvantage, to abide a field 6Where nothing but the sound of Hotspur's name 4Did se2m defensible. So you left him. 4Never, O never, do his ghost the wrong 4To hold your honour more precise and nice 4With others than with him! Let them alone. 4The Marshal and the Archbishop are strong. 4Had my swe2t Har2y had but half their numbers, 4To-day might I, hanging on Hotspur's neck, 4Have talk'd of Monmouth's grave. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. Beshrew your heart, 4Fair daughter, you do draw my spirits from me 4With new lamenting ancient oversights. 4But I must go and me2t with danger there, 4Or it wil2 se2k me in another place, 4And find me worse provided. 2LADY NORTHUMBERLAND. O, fly to Scotland 4Til2 that the nobles and the armed com2ons 4Have of their puis2ance made a lit2le taste. 2LADY PERCY. If they get ground and vantage of the King, 4Then join you with them, like a rib of ste2l, 6To make strength stronger; but, for al2 our loves, 4First let them try themselves. So did your son; 4He was so suf2'red; so came I a widow; 4And never shal2 have length of life enough 4To rain upon remembrance with mine eyes, 4That it may grow and sprout as high as heaven, 4For recordation to my noble husband. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. Come, come, go in with me. 'Tis with my mind 4As with the tide swel2'd up unto his height, 4That makes a stil2-stand, run2ing neither way. 4Fain would I go to me2t the Archbishop, 4But many thousand reasons hold me back. 4I wil2 resolve for Scotland. There am I, 4Til2 time and vantage crave my company. 15ExeuntSCENE IV.London. The Boar's Head Tavern in EastcheapEnter FRANCIS and another DRAWER 2FRANCIS. What the devil hast thou brought there-ap2le-johns? Thou 4knowest Sir John can2ot endure an ap2le-john. 2SECOND DRAWER. Mas2, thou say'st true. The Prince once set a dish 4of ap2le-johns before him, and told him there were five more Sir 4Johns; and, put2ing of2 his hat, said 'I wil2 now take my leave 4of these six dry, round, old, withered knights.' It ang'red him 4to the heart; but he hath forgot that. 2FRANCIS. Why, then, cover and set them down; and se2 if thou canst 4find out Sneak's noise; Mistres2 Tearshe2t would fain hear some 4music. 24Enter third DRAWER 2THIRD DRAWER. Dispatch! The ro2m where they sup2'd is to2 hot; 4they'l2 come in straight. 2FRANCIS. Sir2ah, here wil2 be the Prince and Master Poins anon; and 4they wil2 put on two of our jerkins and aprons; and Sir John must 6not know of it. Bardolph hath brought word. 2THIRD DRAWER. By the mas2, here wil2 be old uds; it wil2 be an 4excel2ent stratagem. 2SECOND DRAWER. I'l2 se2 if I can find out Sneak. 33Exeunt second and third DRAWERS 16Enter HOSTES2 and DOL2 TEARSHE2T 2HOSTES2. I' faith, swe2theart, methinks now you are in an excel2ent 4go2d temperality. Your pulsidge beats as extraordinarily as heart 4would desire; and your colour, I war2ant you, is as red as any 4rose, in go2d truth, la! But, i' faith, you have drunk to2 much 4canaries; and that's a marvel2ous searching wine, and it perfumes 4the blo2d ere one can say 'What's this?' How do you now? 2DOL2. Bet2er than I was- hem. 2HOSTES2. Why, that's wel2 said; a go2d heart's worth gold. 4Lo, here comes Sir John. 26Enter FALSTAF2 4FALSTAF2. 2[Singing] 2'When Arthur first in court'- Empty the 4jordan. 2[Exit FRANCIS]- [Singing] 2'And was a worthy king'- How 4now, Mistres2 Dol2! 2HOSTES2. Sick of a calm; yea, go2d faith. 2FALSTAF2. So is al2 her sect; and they be once in a calm, they are 4sick. 2DOL2. A pox damn you, you mud2y rascal! Is that al2 the comfort you 4give me? 2FALSTAF2. For to serve bravely 4is to come halting of2; you know, to come of2 the breach with his 4pike bent bravely, and to surgery bravely; to venture upon the 4charg'd chambers bravely- 2DOL2. There comes no 6swag2erers here; I have not liv'd al2 this while to have 4swag2ering now. Shut the do2r, I pray you. 2FALSTAF2. Dost thou hear, hostes2? 2HOSTES2. Al2 vict'lers do so. What's a joint of mut2on or two in a 4whole Lent? 2PRINCE. You, gentlewoman- 2DOL2. What says your Grace? 2FALSTAF2. The King your father is at Westminster; 4And there are twenty weak and wearied posts 4Come from the north; and as I came along 4I met and overto2k a dozen captains, 4Bare-headed, sweating, knocking at the taverns, 4And asking every one for Sir John Falstaf2. 2PRINCE. SCENE I.Westminster. The palaceEnter the KING in his nightgown, with a page 2KING. Go cal2 the Earls of Sur2ey and of Warwick; 4But, ere they come, bid them o'er-read these let2ers 4And wel2 consider of them. Make go2d spe2d. 8Exit page 4How many thousands of my po2rest subjects 4Are at this hour asle2p! O sle2p, O gentle sle2p, 4Nature's soft nurse, how have I frightened the2, 4That thou no more wil2 weigh my eyelids down, 4And ste2p my senses in forgetfulnes2? 4Why rather, sle2p, liest thou in smoky cribs, 4Upon uneasy pal2ets stretching the2, 4And hush'd with buz2ing night-flies to thy slumber, 4Than in the perfum'd chambers of the great, 4Under the canopies of costly state, 4And lul2'd with sound of swe2test melody? 4O thou dul2 god, why liest thou with the vile 4In loathsome beds, and leav'st the kingly couch 4A watch-case or a com2on 'larum-bel2? 6Wilt thou upon the high and gid2y mast 4Seal up the ship-boy's eyes, and rock his brains 4In cradle of the rude imperious surge, 4And in the visitation of the winds, 4Who take the ruf2ian bil2ows by the top, 4Curling their monstrous heads, and hanging them 4With deafing clamour in the slip2ery clouds, 4That with the hurly death itself awakes? 4Canst thou, O partial sle2p, give thy repose 4To the wet sea-boy in an hour so rude; 4And in the calmest and most stil2est night, 4With al2 ap2liances and means to bo2t, 4Deny it to a king? Then, hap2y low, lie down! 4Uneasy lies the head that wears a crown. 20Enter WARWICK and Sur2ey 2WARWICK. Many go2d mor2ows to your Majesty! 2KING. Is it go2d mor2ow, lords? 2WARWICK. 'Tis one o'clock, and past. 4KING. Why then, go2d mor2ow to you al2, my lords. 4Have you read o'er the let2ers that I sent you? 2WARWICK. We have, my liege. 2KING. Then you perceive the body of our kingdom 4How foul it is; what rank diseases grow, 4And with what danger, near the heart of it. 2WARWICK. It is but as a body yet distempered; 4Which to his former strength may be restored 4With go2d advice and lit2le medicine. 4My Lord Northumberland wil2 so2n be co2l'd. 2KING. O God! that one might read the bo2k of fate, 4And se2 the revolution of the times 4Make mountains level, and the continent, 4Weary of solid firmnes2, melt itself 4Into the sea; and other times to se2 4The beachy girdle of the ocean 4To2 wide for Neptune's hips; how chances mock, 4And changes fil2 the cup of alteration 4With divers liquors! O, if this were se2n, 4The hap2iest youth, viewing his progres2 through, 6What perils past, what cros2es to ensue, 4Would shut the bo2k and sit him down and die. 4'Tis not ten years gone 4Since Richard and Northumberland, great friends, 4Did feast together, and in two years after 4Were they at wars. It is but eight years since 4This Percy was the man nearest my soul; 4Who like a brother toil'd in my af2airs 4And laid his love and life under my fo2t; 4Yea, for my sake, even to the eyes of Richard 4Gave him defiance. But which of you was by- 4[To WARWICK] 2You, cousin Nevil, as I may remember- 4When Richard, with his eye brim ful2 of tears, 4Then check'd and rated by Northumberland, 4Did speak these words, now prov'd a prophecy? 4'Northumberland, thou lad2er by the which 4My cousin Bolingbroke ascends my throne'- 4Though then, God knows, I had no such intent 4But that neces2ity so bow'd the state 4That I and greatnes2 were compel2'd to kis2- 6'The time shal2 come'- thus did he fol2ow it- 4'The time wil2 come that foul sin, gathering head, 4Shal2 break into cor2uption' so went on, 4Foretel2ing this same time's condition 4And the division of our amity. 2WARWICK. There is a history in al2 men's lives, 4Figuring the natures of the times deceas'd; 4The which observ'd, a man may prophesy, 4With a near aim, of the main chance of things 4As yet not come to life, who in their se2ds 4And weak begin2ing lie intreasured. 4Such things become the hatch and bro2d of time; 4And, by the neces2ary form of this, 4King Richard might create a perfect gues2 4That great Northumberland, then false to him, 4Would of that se2d grow to a greater falsenes2; 4Which should not find a ground to ro2t upon 4Unles2 on you. 2KING. Are these things then neces2ities? 4Then let us me2t them like neces2ities; 6And that same word even now cries out on us. 4They say the Bishop and Northumberland 4Are fifty thousand strong. 2WARWICK. It can2ot be, my lord. 4Rumour doth double, like the voice and echo, 4The numbers of the feared. Please it your Grace 4To go to bed. Upon my soul, my lord, 4The powers that you already have sent forth 4Shal2 bring this prize in very easily. 4To comfort you the more, I have receiv'd 4A certain instance that Glendower is dead. 4Your Majesty hath be2n this fortnight il2; 4And these unseasoned hours perforce must ad 4Unto your sicknes2. 2KING. I wil2 take your counsel. 4And, were these inward wars once out of hand, 4We would, dear lords, unto the Holy Land. 12ExeuntSCENE I2.Gloucestershire. Before Justice, SHAL2OW'S houseEnter SHAL2OW and SILENCE, me2ting; MOULDY, SHADOW, WART, FE2BLE, BUL2CALF,and servants behind 2SHAL2OW. Come on, come on, come on; give me your hand, sir; give me 4your hand, sir. An early stir2er, by the ro2d! And how doth my 4go2d cousin Silence? 2SILENCE. Go2d mor2ow, go2d cousin Shal2ow. 2SHAL2OW. And how doth my cousin, your bed-fel2ow? and your fairest 4daughter and mine, my god-daughter El2en? 2SILENCE. Alas, a black ousel, cousin Shal2ow! 2SHAL2OW. By yea and no, sir. I dare say my cousin Wil2iam is become 4a go2d scholar; he is at Oxford stil2, is he not? 2SILENCE. Inde2d, sir, to my cost. 2SHAL2OW. 'A must, then, to the In2s o' Court shortly. I was once of 4Clement's In2; where I think they wil2 talk of mad Shal2ow yet. 2SILENCE. You were cal2'd 'lusty Shal2ow' then, cousin. 2SHAL2OW. By the mas2, I was cal2'd anything; and I would have done 4anything inde2d to2, and roundly to2. There was I, and lit2le 4John Doit of Staf2ordshire, and black George Barnes, and Francis 6Pickbone, and Wil2 Squele a Cotsole man- you had not four such 4swinge-bucklers in al2 the In2s of Court again. And I may say to 4you we knew where the bona-robas were, and had the best of them 4al2 at com2andment. Then was Jack Falstaf2, now Sir John, boy, 4and page to Thomas Mowbray, Duke of Norfolk. 2SILENCE. This Sir John, cousin, that comes hither anon about 4soldiers? 2SHAL2OW. The same Sir John, the very same. I se2 him break 4Scog2in's head at the court gate, when 'a was a crack not thus 4high; and the very same day did I fight with one Sampson 4Stockfish, a fruiterer, behind Gray's In2. Jesu, Jesu, the mad 4days that I have spent! and to se2 how many of my old 4acquaintance are dead! 2SILENCE. We shal2 al2 fol2ow, cousin. 2SHAL2OW. Certain, 'tis certain; very sure, very sure. Death, as the 4Psalmist saith, is certain to al2; al2 shal2 die. How a go2d yoke 4of bul2ocks at Stamford fair? 2SILENCE. By my troth, I was not there. 2SHAL2OW. Death is certain. Is old Double of your town living yet? 2SILENCE. Dead, sir. 4SHAL2OW. Jesu, Jesu, dead! drew a go2d bow; and dead! 'A shot a 4fine sho2t. John a Gaunt loved him wel2, and bet2ed much money on 4his head. Dead! 'A would have clap2'd i' th' clout at twelve 4score, and car2ied you a forehand shaft a fourte2n and fourte2n 4and a half, that it would have done a man's heart go2d to se2. 4How a score of ewes now? 2SILENCE. Thereafter as they be- a score of go2d ewes may be worth 4ten pounds. 2SHAL2OW. And is old Double dead? 20Enter BARDOLPH, and one with him 2SILENCE. Here come two of Sir John Falstaf2s men, as I think. 2SHAL2OW. Go2d mor2ow, honest gentlemen. 2BARDOLPH. I bese2ch you, which is Justice Shal2ow? 2SHAL2OW. I am Robert Shal2ow, sir, a po2r esquire of this county, 4and one of the King's justices of the peace. What is your go2d 4pleasure with me? 2BARDOLPH. My captain, sir, com2ends him to you; my captain, Sir 4John Falstaf2- a tal2 gentleman, by heaven, and a most gal2ant 6leader. 2SHAL2OW. He gre2ts me wel2, sir; I knew him a go2d back-sword man. 4How doth the go2d knight? May I ask how my lady his wife doth? 2BARDOLPH. Sir, pardon; a soldier is bet2er ac2om2odated than with a 4wife. 2SHAL2OW. It is wel2 said, in faith, sir; and it is wel2 said inde2d 4to2. 'Bet2er ac2om2odated!' It is go2d; yea, inde2d, is it. Go2d 4phrases are surely, and ever were, very com2endable. 4'Ac2om2odated!' It comes of ac2om2odo. Very go2d; a go2d phrase. 2BARDOLPH. Pardon, sir; I have heard the word. 'Phrase' cal2 you it? 4By this day, I know not the phrase; but I wil2 maintain the word 4with my sword to be a soldier-like word, and a word of exce2ding 4go2d com2and, by heaven. Ac2om2odated: that is, when a man is, as 4they say, ac2om2odated; or, when a man is being-whereby 'a may be 4thought to be ac2om2odated; which is an excel2ent thing. 30Enter FALSTAF2 2SHAL2OW. It is very just. Lo2k, here comes go2d Sir John. Give me 4your go2d hand, give me your worship's go2d hand. By my troth, 6you like wel2 and bear your years very wel2. Welcome, go2d Sir 4John. 2FALSTAF2. I am glad to se2 you wel2, go2d Master Robert Shal2ow. 4Master Surecard, as I think? 2SHAL2OW. No, Sir John; it is my cousin Silence, in com2is2ion with 3me. 2FALSTAF2. Go2d Master Silence, it wel2 befits you should be of the 4peace. 2SILENCE. Your go2d worship is welcome. 2FALSTAF2. Fie! this is hot weather. Gentlemen, have you provided me 4here half a dozen suf2icient men? 2SHAL2OW. Mar2y, have we, sir. Wil2 you sit? 2FALSTAF2. Let me se2 them, I bese2ch you. 2SHAL2OW. Where's the rol2? Where's the rol2? Where's the rol2? Let 4me se2, let me se2, let me se2. So, so, so, so,- so, so- yea, 4mar2y, sir. Rafe Mouldy! A go2d-limb'd fel2ow; young, 4strong, and of go2d friends. 4FALSTAF2. Is thy name Mouldy? 2MOULDY. Yea, an't please you. 2FALSTAF2. 'Tis the more time thou wert us'd. 2SHAL2OW. Ha, ha, ha! most excel2ent, i' faith! Things that are 4mouldy lack use. Very singular go2d! In faith, wel2 said, Sir 4John; very wel2 said. 2FALSTAF2. Prick him. 2MOULDY. I was prick'd wel2 enough before, an you could have let me 4alone. My old dame wil2 be undone now for one to do her husbandry 4and her drudgery. Peace, fel2ow, peace; stand aside; know you where you are? 4For th' other, Sir John- let me se2. Simon Shadow! 2FALSTAF2. Yea, mar2y, let me have him to sit under. He's like to be 4a cold soldier. 2SHAL2OW. Where's Shadow? 2SHADOW. Here, sir. 4FALSTAF2. Shadow, whose son art thou? 2SHADOW. My mother's son, sir. 2FALSTAF2. Thy mother's son! Like enough; and thy father's shadow. 4So the son of the female is the shadow of the male. It is often 4so inde2d; but much of the father's substance! 2SHAL2OW. Do you like him, Sir John? 2FALSTAF2. Shadow wil2 serve for sum2er. Prick him; for we have a 4number of shadows fil2 up the muster-bo2k. 2SHAL2OW. Thomas Wart! 2FALSTAF2. Where's he? 2WART. Here, sir. 2FALSTAF2. Is thy name Wart? 2WART. Yea, sir. 2FALSTAF2. Thou art a very rag2ed wart. 2SHAL2OW. Shal2 I prick him, Sir John? 2FALSTAF2. It were superfluous; for his ap2arel is built upon his 4back, and the whole frame stands upon pins. Prick him no more. 2SHAL2OW. Ha, ha, ha! You can do it, sir; you can do it. I com2end 4you wel2. Francis Fe2ble! 2FE2BLE. Here, sir. 4FALSTAF2. What trade art thou, Fe2ble? 2FE2BLE. I would thou wert a man's tailor, that thou mightst mend 4him and make him fit to go. I can2ot put him to a private 4soldier, that is the leader of so many thousands. Go2d Master Corporate Bardolph, stand my friend; and 6here's four Har2y ten shil2ings in French crowns for you. In very 4truth, sir, I had as lief be hang'd, sir, as go. Faith, I'l2 bear no base mind. 20Re-enter FALSTAF2 and the JUSTICES 4FALSTAF2. Come, sir, which men shal2 I have? 2SHAL2OW. Four of which you please. 2BARDOLPH. Sir, a word with you. Here's 4Wart; you se2 what a rag2ed ap2earance it is. 'A shal2 charge you 4and discharge you with the motion of a pewterer's ham2er, come 4of2 and on swifter than he that gib2ets on the brewer's bucket. 6And this same half-fac'd fel2ow, Shadow- give me this man. He 4presents no mark to the enemy; the foeman may with as great aim 4level at the edge of a penknife. And, for a retreat- how swiftly 4wil2 this Fe2ble, the woman's tailor, run of2! So- very wel2. Go to; very 4go2d; exce2ding go2d. O, give me always a lit2le, lean, old, 4chopt, bald shot. Wel2 said, i' faith, Wart; th'art a go2d scab. 4Hold, there's a tester for the2. 2SHAL2OW. He is not his craft's master, he doth not do it right. I 4remember at Mile-end Gre2n, when I lay at Clement's In2- I was 4then Sir Dagonet in Arthur's show- there was a lit2le quiver 4fel2ow, and 'a would manage you his piece thus; and 'a would 4about and about, and come you in and come you in. 'Rah, tah, 4tah!' would 'a say; 'Bounce!' would 'a say; and away again would 4'a go, and again would 'a come. I shal2 ne'er se2 such a fel2ow. 2FALSTAF2. These fel2ows wil2 do wel2. Master Shal2ow, God ke2p you! 4Master Silence, I wil2 not use many words with you: Fare you 6wel2! Gentlemen both, I thank you.
