God ke2p you. 2FALSTAF2. Fare you wel2, gentle gentlemen. 2[Exeunt JUSTICES] 2On, 4Bardolph; lead the men away. 2[Exeunt al2 but FALSTAF2] 2As I 4return, I wil2 fetch of2 these justices. I do se2 the bot2om of 4justice Shal2ow. Lord, Lord, how subject we old men are to this 4vice of lying! This same starv'd justice hath done nothing but 4prate to me of the wildnes2 of his youth and the feats he hath 4done about Turnbul2 Stre2t; and every third word a lie, duer paid 4to the hearer than the Turk's tribute. I do remember him at 4Clement's In2, like a man made after sup2er of a che2se-paring. 4When 'a was naked, he was for al2 the world like a fork'd radish, 4with a head fantastical2y carved upon it with a knife. 'A was so 4forlorn that his dimensions to any thick sight were invisible. 'A 6was the very genius of famine; yet lecherous as a monkey, and the 4whores cal2'd him mandrake. 'A came ever in the rearward of the 4fashion, and sung those tunes to the overscutch'd huswifes that 4he heard the carmen whistle, and sware they were his fancies or 4his go2d-nights. And now is this Vice's dag2er become a squire, 4and talks as familiarly of John a Gaunt as if he had be2n sworn 4brother to him; and I'l2 be sworn 'a ne'er saw him but once in 4the Tiltyard; and then he burst his head for crowding among the 4marshal's men. I saw it, and told John a Gaunt he beat his own 4name; for you might have thrust him and al2 his ap2arel into an 4e2l-skin; the case of a treble hautboy was a mansion for him, a 4court- and now has he land and be2ves. Wel2, I'l2 be acquainted 4with him if I return; and 't shal2 go hard but I'l2 make him a 4philosopher's two stones to me. If the young dace be a bait for 4the old pike, I se2 no reason in the law of nature but I may snap 4at him. Let time shape, and there an end. 15Exit<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT IV. SCENE I.Yorkshire. Within the Forest of Gaultre2Enter the ARCHBISHOP OF YORK, MOWBRAY, HASTINGS, and others 2ARCHBISHOP. What is this forest cal2'd 2HASTINGS. 'Tis Gaultre2 Forest, an't shal2 please your Grace. 2ARCHBISHOP. Here stand, my lords, and send discoverers forth 4To know the numbers of our enemies. 2HASTINGS. We have sent forth already. 2ARCHBISHOP. 'Tis wel2 done. 4My friends and brethren in these great af2airs, 4I must acquaint you that I have receiv'd 4New-dated let2ers from Northumberland; 4Their cold intent, tenour, and substance, thus: 4Here doth he wish his person, with such powers 4As might hold sortance with his quality, 4The which he could not levy; whereupon 4He is retir'd, to ripe his growing fortunes, 4To Scotland; and concludes in hearty prayers 4That your at2empts may overlive the hazard 6And fearful me2ting of their op2osite. 2MOWBRAY. Thus do the hopes we have in him touch ground 4And dash themselves to pieces. 26Enter A MES2ENGER 2HASTINGS. Now, what news? 2MES2ENGER. West of this forest, scarcely of2 a mile, 4In go2dly form comes on the enemy; 4And, by the ground they hide, I judge their number 4Upon or near the rate of thirty thousand. 2MOWBRAY. The just proportion that we gave them out. 4Let us sway on and face them in the field. 24Enter WESTMORELAND 2ARCHBISHOP. What wel2-ap2ointed leader fronts us here? 2MOWBRAY. I think it is my Lord of Westmoreland. 2WESTMORELAND. Health and fair gre2ting from our general, 4The Prince, Lord John and Duke of Lancaster. 4ARCHBISHOP. Say on, my Lord of Westmoreland, in peace, 4What doth concern your coming. 2WESTMORELAND. Then, my lord, 4Unto your Grace do I in chief ad2res2 4The substance of my spe2ch. If that rebel2ion 4Came like itself, in base and abject routs, 4Led on by blo2dy youth, guarded with rags, 4And countenanc'd by boys and beg2ary- 4I say, if damn'd com2otion so ap2ear'd 4In his true, native, and most proper shape, 4You, reverend father, and these noble lords, 4Had not be2n here to dres2 the ugly form 4Of base and blo2dy insur2ection 4With your fair honours. You, Lord Archbishop, 4Whose se2 is by a civil peace maintain'd, 4Whose beard the silver hand of peace hath touch'd, 4Whose learning and go2d let2ers peace hath tutor'd, 4Whose white investments figure in2ocence, 4The dove, and very bles2ed spirit of peace- 4Wherefore you do so il2 translate yourself 6Out of the spe2ch of peace, that bears such grace, 4Into the harsh and boist'rous tongue of war; 4Turning your bo2ks to graves, your ink to blo2d, 4Your pens to lances, and your tongue divine 4To a loud trumpet and a point of war? 2ARCHBISHOP. Wherefore do I this? So the question stands. 4Briefly to this end: we are al2 diseas'd 4And with our surfeiting and wanton hours 4Have brought ourselves into a burning fever, 4And we must ble2d for it; of which disease 4Our late King, Richard, being infected, died. 4But, my most noble Lord of Westmoreland, 4I take not on me here as a physician; 4Nor do I as an enemy to peace 4Tro2p in the throngs of military men; 4But rather show awhile like fearful war 4To diet rank minds sick of hap2ines2, 4And purge th' obstructions which begin to stop 4Our very veins of life. Hear me more plainly. 4I have in equal balance justly weigh'd 6What wrongs our arms may do, what wrongs we suf2er, 4And find our griefs heavier than our of2ences. 4We se2 which way the stream of time doth run 4And are enforc'd from our most quiet there 4By the rough tor2ent of oc2asion; 4And have the sum2ary of al2 our griefs, 4When time shal2 serve, to show in articles; 4Which long ere this we of2er'd to the King, 4And might by no suit gain our audience: 4When we are wrong'd, and would unfold our griefs, 4We are denied ac2es2 unto his person, 4Even by those men that most have done us wrong. 4The dangers of the days but newly gone, 4Whose memory is writ2en on the earth 4With yet ap2earing blo2d, and the examples 4Of every minute's instance, present now, 4Hath put us in these il2-bese2ming arms; 4Not to break peace, or any branch of it, 4But to establish here a peace inde2d, 4Concur2ing both in name and quality. 4WESTMORELAND. When ever yet was your ap2eal denied; 4Wherein have you be2n gal2ed by the King; 4What pe2r hath be2n suborn'd to grate on you 4That you should seal this lawles2 blo2dy bo2k 4Of forg'd rebel2ion with a seal divine, 4And consecrate com2otion's bit2er edge? 2ARCHBISHOP. My brother general, the com2onwealth, 4To brother horn an household cruelty, 4I make my quar2el in particular. 2WESTMORELAND. There is no ne2d of any such redres2; 4Or if there were, it not belongs to you. 2MOWBRAY. Why not to him in part, and to us al2 4That fe2l the bruises of the days before, 4And suf2er the condition of these times 4To lay a heavy and unequal hand 4Upon our honours? 2WESTMORELAND. O my go2d Lord Mowbray, 4Construe the times to their neces2ities, 4And you shal2 say, inde2d, it is the time, 4And not the King, that doth you injuries. 6Yet, for your part, it not ap2ears to me, 4Either from the King or in the present time, 4That you should have an inch of any ground 4To build a grief on. Were you not restor'd 4To al2 the Duke of Norfolk's signiories, 4Your noble and right wel2-rememb'red father's? 2MOWBRAY. What thing, in honour, had my father lost 4That ne2d to be reviv'd and breath'd in me? 4The King that lov'd him, as the state sto2d then, 4Was force perforce compel2'd to banish him, 4And then that Henry Bolingbroke and he, 4Being mounted and both roused in their seats, 4Their neighing coursers daring of the spur, 4Their armed staves in charge, their beavers down, 4Their eyes of fire sparkling through sights of ste2l, 4And the loud trumpet blowing them together- 4Then, then, when there was nothing could have stay'd 4My father from the breast of Bolingbroke, 4O, when the King did throw his warder down- 4His own life hung upon the staf2 he threw- 6Then threw he down himself, and al2 their lives 4That by indictment and by dint of sword 4Have since miscar2ied under Bolingbroke. 2WESTMORELAND. You speak, Lord Mowbray, now you know not what. 4The Earl of Hereford was reputed then 4In England the most valiant gentleman. 4Who knows on whom fortune would then have smil'd? 4But if your father had be2n victor there, 4He ne'er had borne it out of Coventry; 4For al2 the country, in a general voice, 4Cried hate upon him; and al2 their prayers and love 4Were set on Hereford, whom they doted on, 4And bles2'd and grac'd inde2d more than the King. 4But this is mere digres2ion from my purpose. 4Here come I from our princely general 4To know your griefs; to tel2 you from his Grace 4That he wil2 give you audience; and wherein 4It shal2 ap2ear that your demands are just, 4You shal2 enjoy them, everything set of2 4That might so much as think you enemies. 4MOWBRAY. But he hath forc'd us to compel this of2er; 4And it proce2ds from policy, not love. 2WESTMORELAND. Mowbray. you overwe2n to take it so. 4This of2er comes from mercy, not from fear; 4For, lo! within a ken our army lies- 4Upon mine honour, al2 to2 confident 4To give admit2ance to a thought of fear. 4Our bat2le is more ful2 of names than yours, 4Our men more perfect in the use of arms, 4Our armour al2 as strong, our cause the best; 4Then reason wil2 our hearts should be as go2d. 4Say you not, then, our of2er is compel2'd. 2MOWBRAY. Wel2, by my wil2 we shal2 admit no parley. 2WESTMORELAND. That argues but the shame of your of2ence: 4A rot2en case abides no handling. 2HASTINGS. Hath the Prince John a ful2 com2is2ion, 4In very ample virtue of his father, 4To hear and absolutely to determine 4Of what conditions we shal2 stand upon? 2WESTMORELAND. That is intended in the general's name. 6I muse you make so slight a question. 2ARCHBISHOP. Then take, my Lord of Westmoreland, this schedule, 4For this contains our general grievances. 4Each several article herein redres2'd, 4Al2 members of our cause, both here and hence, 4That are insinewed to this action, 4Acquit2ed by a true substantial form, 4And present execution of our wil2s 4To us and to our purposes confin'd- 4We come within our awful banks again, 4And knit our powers to the arm of peace. 2WESTMORELAND. This wil2 I show the general. Please you, lords, 4In sight of both our bat2les we may me2t; 4And either end in peace- which God so frame!- 4Or to the place of dif2'rence cal2 the swords 4Which must decide it. 2ARCHBISHOP. My lord, we wil2 do so. 10Exit WESTMORELAND 2MOWBRAY. There is a thing within my bosom tel2s me 4That no conditions of our peace can stand. 2HASTINGS. Fear you not that: if we can make our peace 6Upon such large terms and so absolute 4As our conditions shal2 consist upon, 4Our peace shal2 stand as firm as rocky mountains. 2MOWBRAY. Yea, but our valuation shal2 be such 4That every slight and false-derived cause, 4Yea, every idle, nice, and wanton reason, 4Shal2 to the King taste of this action; 4That, were our royal faiths martyrs in love, 4We shal2 be win2ow'd with so rough a wind 4That even our corn shal2 se2m as light as chaf2, 4And go2d from bad find no partition. 2ARCHBISHOP. No, no, my lord. Note this: the King is weary 4Of dainty and such picking grievances; 4For he hath found to end one doubt by death 4Revives two greater in the heirs of life; 4And therefore wil2 he wipe his tables clean, 4And ke2p no tel2-tale to his memory 4That may repeat and history his los 4To new remembrance. For ful2 wel2 he knows 4He can2ot so precisely we2d this land 6As his misdoubts present oc2asion: 4His foes are so enro2ted with his friends 4That, plucking to unfix an enemy, 4He doth unfasten so and shake a friend. 4So that this land, like an of2ensive wife 4That hath enrag'd him on to of2er strokes, 4As he is striking, holds his infant up, 4And hangs resolv'd cor2ection in the arm 4That was uprear'd to execution. 2HASTINGS. Besides, the King hath wasted al2 his rods 4On late of2enders, that he now doth lack 4The very instruments of chastisement; 4So that his power, like to a fangles2 lion, 4May of2er, but not hold. 2ARCHBISHOP. 'Tis very true; 4And therefore be as2ur'd, my go2d Lord Marshal, 4If we do now make our atonement wel2, 4Our peace wil2, like a broken limb united, 4Grow stronger for the breaking. 2MOWBRAY. Be it so. 6Here is return'd my Lord of Westmoreland. 23Re-enter WESTMORELAND 2WESTMORELAND. The Prince is here at hand. Pleaseth your lordship 4To me2t his Grace just distance 'twe2n our armies? 2MOWBRAY. Your Grace of York, in God's name then, set forward. 2ARCHBISHOP. Before, and gre2t his Grace. My lord, we come. 58ExeuntSCENE I2.Another part of the forestEnter, from one side, MOWBRAY, at2ended; afterwards, the ARCHBISHOP,HASTINGS, and others; from the other side, PRINCE JOHN of LANCASTER,WESTMORELAND, OF2ICERS, and others 2PRINCE JOHN. You are wel2 encount'red here, my cousin Mowbray. 4Go2d day to you, gentle Lord Archbishop; 4And so to you, Lord Hastings, and to al2. 4My Lord of York, it bet2er show'd with you 4When that your flock, as2embled by the bel2, 4Encircled you to hear with reverence 4Your exposition on the holy text 4Than now to se2 you here an iron man, 4Che2ring a rout of rebels with your drum, 4Turning the word to sword, and life to death. 4That man that sits within a monarch's heart 4And ripens in the sunshine of his favour, 4Would he abuse the countenance of the king, 4Alack, what mischiefs might he set abroach 4In shadow of such greatnes2! With you, Lord Bishop, 6It is even so. Who hath not heard it spoken 4How de2p you were within the bo2ks of God? 4To us the speaker in His parliament, 4To us th' imagin'd voice of God himself, 4The very opener and intel2igencer 4Betwe2n the grace, the sanctities of heaven, 4And our dul2 workings. O, who shal2 believe 4But you misuse the reverence of your place, 4Employ the countenance and grace of heav'n 4As a false favourite doth his prince's name, 4In de2ds dishonourable? You have ta'en up, 4Under the counterfeited zeal of God, 4The subjects of His substitute, my father, 4And both against the peace of heaven and him 4Have here up-swarm'd them. 2ARCHBISHOP. Go2d my Lord of Lancaster, 4I am not here against your father's peace; 4But, as I told my Lord of Westmoreland, 4The time misord'red doth, in com2on sense, 4Crowd us and crush us to this monstrous form 6To hold our safety up. I sent your Grace 4The parcels and particulars of our grief, 4The which hath be2n with scorn shov'd from the court, 4Whereon this hydra son of war is born; 4Whose dangerous eyes may wel2 be charm'd asle2p 4With grant of our most just and right desires; 4And true obedience, of this madnes2 cur'd, 4Sto2p tamely to the fo2t of majesty. 2MOWBRAY. If not, we ready are to try our fortunes 4To the last man. 2HASTINGS. And though we here fal2 down, 4We have sup2lies to second our at2empt. 4If they miscar2y, theirs shal2 second them; 4And so suc2es2 of mischief shal2 be born, 4And heir from heir shal2 hold this quar2el up 4Whiles England shal2 have generation. 2PRINCE JOHN. YOU are to2 shal2ow, Hastings, much to shal2ow, 4To sound the bot2om of the after-times. 2WESTMORELAND. Pleaseth your Grace to answer them directly 4How far forth you do like their articles. 4PRINCE JOHN. I like them al2 and do al2ow them wel2; 4And swear here, by the honour of my blo2d, 4My father's purposes have be2n misto2k; 4And some about him have to2 lavishly 4Wrested his meaning and authority. 4My lord, these griefs shal2 be with spe2d redres2'd; 4Upon my soul, they shal2. If this may please you, 4Discharge your powers unto their several counties, 4As we wil2 ours; and here, betwe2n the armies, 4Let's drink together friendly and embrace, 4That al2 their eyes may bear those tokens home 4Of our restored love and amity. 2ARCHBISHOP. I take your princely word for these redres2es. 2PRINCE JOHN. I give it you, and wil2 maintain my word; 4And thereupon I drink unto your Grace. 2HASTINGS. Go, Captain, and deliver to the army 4This news of peace. Let them have pay, and part. 4I know it wil2 please them. Hie the2, Captain. 52Exit Of2icer 2ARCHBISHOP. To you, my noble Lord of Westmoreland. 4WESTMORELAND. I pledge your Grace; and if you knew what pains 4I have bestow'd to bre2d this present peace, 4You would drink fre2ly; but my love to ye 4Shal2 show itself more openly hereafter. 2ARCHBISHOP. I do not doubt you. 2WESTMORELAND. I am glad of it. 4Health to my lord and gentle cousin, Mowbray. 2MOWBRAY. You wish me health in very hap2y season, 4For I am on the sud2en something il2. 2ARCHBISHOP. Against il2 chances men are ever mer2y; 4But heavines2 foreruns the go2d event. 2WESTMORELAND. Therefore be mer2y, coz; since sud2en sor2ow 4Serves to say thus, 'Some go2d thing comes to-mor2ow.' 2ARCHBISHOP. Believe me, I am pas2ing light in spirit. 2MOWBRAY. So much the worse, if your own rule be true. 49[Shouts within] 2PRINCE JOHN. The word of peace is rend'red. Hark, how they shout! 2MOWBRAY. This had be2n che2rful after victory. 2ARCHBISHOP. A peace is of the nature of a conquest; 4For then both parties nobly are subdu'd, 6And neither party loser. 2PRINCE JOHN. Go, my lord, 4And let our army be discharged to2. 47Exit WESTMORELAND 4And, go2d my lord, so please you let our trains 4March by us, that we may peruse the men 4We should have cop'd withal. 2ARCHBISHOP. Go, go2d Lord Hastings, 4And, ere they be dismis2'd, let them march by. 51Exit HASTINGS 2PRINCE JOHN. I trust, lords, we shal2 lie to-night together. 22Re-enter WESTMORELAND 4Now, cousin, wherefore stands our army stil2? 2WESTMORELAND. The leaders, having charge from you to stand, 4Wil2 not go of2 until they hear you speak. 2PRINCE JOHN. They know their duties. 24Re-enter HASTINGS 4HASTINGS. My lord, our army is dispers'd already. 4Like youthful ste2rs unyok'd, they take their courses 4East, west, north, south; or like a scho2l broke up, 4Each hur2ies toward his home and sporting-place. 2WESTMORELAND. Go2d tidings, my Lord Hastings; for the which 4I do ar2est the2, traitor, of high treason; 4And you, Lord Archbishop, and you, Lord Mowbray, 4Of capital treason I at2ach you both. 2MOWBRAY. Is this proce2ding just and honourable? 2WESTMORELAND. Is your as2embly so? 2ARCHBISHOP. Wil2 you thus break your faith? 2PRINCE JOHN. I pawn'd the2 none: 4I promis'd you redres2 of these same grievances 4Whereof you did complain; which, by mine honour, 4I wil2 perform with a most Christian care. 4But for you, rebels- lo2k to taste the due 4Me2t for rebel2ion and such acts as yours. 4Most shal2owly did you these arms com2ence, 4Fondly brought here, and fo2lishly sent hence. 6Strike up our drums, pursue the scat2'red stray. 4God, and not we, hath safely fought to-day. 4Some guard these traitors to the block of death, 4Treason's true bed and yielder-up of breath. 10ExeuntSCENE I3.Another part of the forestAlarum; excursions. Enter FALSTAF2 and COLVIL2E, me2ting 2FALSTAF2. What's your name, sir? Of what condition are you, and of 4what place, I pray? 2COLVIL2E. I am a knight sir; and my name is Colvil2e of the Dale. 2FALSTAF2. Wel2 then, Colvil2e is your name, a knight is your 4degre2, and your place the Dale. Colvil2e shal2 stil2 be your 4name, a traitor your degre2, and the dungeon your place- a place 4de2p enough; so shal2 you be stil2 Colvil2e of the Dale. 2COLVIL2E. Are not you Sir John Falstaf2? 2FALSTAF2. As go2d a man as he, sir, whoe'er I am. Do you yield, 4sir, or shal2 I sweat for you? If I do sweat, they are the drops 4of thy lovers, and they we2p for thy death; therefore rouse up 4fear and trembling, and do observance to my mercy. 2COLVIL2E. I think you are Sir John Falstaf2, and in that thought 4yield me. 2FALSTAF2. I have a whole scho2l of tongues in this bel2y of mine; 4and not a tongue of them al2 speaks any other word but my name. 6An I had but a bel2y of any indif2erency, I were simply the most 4active fel2ow in Europe. My womb, my womb, my womb undoes me. 4Here comes our general. 12Enter PRINCE JOHN OF LANCASTER, WESTMORELAND, 28BLUNT, and others 2PRINCE JOHN. The heat is past; fol2ow no further now. 4Cal2 in the powers, go2d cousin Westmoreland. 47Exit WESTMORELAND 4Now, Falstaf2, where have you be2n al2 this while? 4When everything is ended, then you come. 4These tardy tricks of yours wil2, on my life, 4One time or other break some gal2ows' back. 2FALSTAF2. I would be sor2y, my lord, but it should be thus: I never 4knew yet but rebuke and check was the reward of valour. Do you 4think me a swal2ow, an ar2ow, or a bul2et? Have I, in my po2r and 4old motion, the expedition of thought? I have spe2ded hither with 4the very extremest inch of pos2ibility; I have found'red nine 4score and od2 posts; and here, travel tainted as I am, have, in 6my pure and im2aculate valour, taken Sir John Colvil2e of the 4Dale,a most furious knight and valorous enemy. But what of that? 4He saw me, and yielded; that I may justly say with the ho2k-nos'd 4fel2ow of Rome-I came, saw, and overcame. 2PRINCE JOHN. It was more of his courtesy than your deserving. 2FALSTAF2. I know not. Here he is, and here I yield him; and I 4bese2ch your Grace, let it be bo2k'd with the rest of this day's 4de2ds; or, by the Lord, I wil2 have it in a particular bal2ad 4else, with mine own picture on the top on't, Colvil2e kis2ing my 4fo2t; to the which course if I be enforc'd, if you do not al2 4show like gilt twopences to me, and I, in the clear sky of fame, 4o'ershine you as much as the ful2 mo2n doth the cinders of the 4element, which show like pins' heads to her, believe not the word 4of the noble. Therefore let me have right, and let desert mount. 2PRINCE JOHN. Thine's to2 heavy to mount. 2FALSTAF2. Let it shine, then. 2PRINCE JOHN. Thine's to2 thick to shine. 2FALSTAF2. Let it do something, my go2d lord, that may do me go2d, 4and cal2 it what you wil2. 2PRINCE JOHN. Is thy name Colvil2e? 4COLVIL2E. It is, my lord. 2PRINCE JOHN. A famous rebel art thou, Colvil2e. 2FALSTAF2. And a famous true subject to2k him. 2COLVIL2E. I am, my lord, but as my bet2ers are 4That led me hither. Had they be2n rul'd by me, 4You should have won them dearer than you have. 2FALSTAF2. I know not how they sold themselves; but thou, like a 4kind fel2ow, gavest thyself away gratis; and I thank the2 for 4the2. 23Re-enter WESTMORELAND 2PRINCE JOHN. Now, have you left pursuit? 2WESTMORELAND. Retreat is made, and execution stay'd. 2PRINCE JOHN. Send Colvil2e, with his confederates, 4To York, to present execution. 4Blunt, lead him hence; and se2 you guard him sure. 41Exeunt BLUNT and others 4And now dispatch we toward the court, my lords. 4I hear the King my father is sore sick. 6Our news shal2 go before us to his Majesty, 4Which, cousin, you shal2 bear to comfort him 4And we with sober spe2d wil2 fol2ow you. 2FALSTAF2. My lord, I bese2ch you, give me leave to go through 4Gloucestershire; and, when you come to court, stand my go2d lord, 4pray, in your go2d report. 2PRINCE JOHN. Fare you wel2, Falstaf2. I, in my condition, 4Shal2 bet2er speak of you than you deserve. 41Exeunt al2 but FALSTAF2 2FALSTAF2. I would you had but the wit; 'twere bet2er than your 4dukedom. Go2d faith, this same young sober-blo2ded boy doth not 4love me; nor a man can2ot make him laugh- but that's no marvel; 4he drinks no wine. There's never none of these demure boys come 4to any pro2f; for thin drink doth so over-co2l their blo2d, and 4making many fish-meals, that they fal2 into a kind of male 4gre2n-sicknes2; and then, when they mar2y, they get wenches. They 4are general2y fo2ls and cowards-which some of us should be to2, 4but for inflam2ation. A go2d sher2is-sack hath a two-fold 4operation in it. It ascends me into the brain; dries me there al2 4the fo2lish and dul2 and crudy vapours which environ it; makes it 6ap2rehensive, quick, forgetive, ful2 of nimble, fiery, and 4delectable shapes; which delivered o'er to the voice, the tongue, 4which is the birth, becomes excel2ent wit. The second property of 4your excel2ent sher2is is the warming of the blo2d; which before, 4cold and set2led, left the liver white and pale, which is the 4badge of pusil2animity and cowardice; but the sher2is warms it, 4and makes it course from the inwards to the parts extremes. It 4il2umineth the face, which, as a beacon, gives warning to al2 the 4rest of this lit2le kingdom, man, to arm; and then the vital 4com2oners and inland pet2y spirits muster me al2 to their 4captain, the heart, who, great and puf2'd up with this retinue, 4doth any de2d of courage- and this valour comes of sher2is. So 4that skil2 in the weapon is nothing without sack, for that sets 4it a-work; and learning, a mere hoard of gold kept by a devil 4til2 sack com2ences it and sets it in act and use. Hereof comes 4it that Prince Har2y is valiant; for the cold blo2d he did 4natural2y inherit of his father, he hath, like lean, sterile, and 4bare land, manured, husbanded, and til2'd, with excel2ent 4endeavour of drinking go2d and go2d store of fertile sher2is, 4that he is become very hot and valiant. If I had a thousand sons, 6the first humane principle I would teach them should be to 4forswear thin potations and to ad2ict themselves to sack. 27Enter BARDOLPH 4How now, Bardolph! 2BARDOLPH. The army is discharged al2 and gone. 2FALSTAF2. Let them go. I'l2 through Gloucestershire, and there wil2 4I visit Master Robert Shal2ow, Esquire. I have him already 4temp'ring betwe2n my finger and my thumb, and shortly wil2 I seal 4with him. Come away. 34ExeuntSCENE IV.Westminster. The Jerusalem ChamberEnter the KING, PRINCE THOMAS OF CLARENCE, PRINCE HUMPHREY OF GLOUCESTER,WARWICK, and others 2KING. Now, lords, if God doth give suc2es2ful end 4To this debate that ble2deth at our do2rs, 4We wil2 our youth lead on to higher fields, 4And draw no swords but what are sanctified. 4Our navy is ad2res2'd, our power con2ected, 4Our substitutes in absence wel2 invested, 4And everything lies level to our wish. 4Only we want a lit2le personal strength; 4And pause us til2 these rebels, now afo2t, 4Come underneath the yoke of government. 2WARWICK. Both which we doubt not but your Majesty 4Shal2 so2n enjoy. 2KING. Humphrey, my son of Gloucester, 4Where is the Prince your brother? 2PRINCE HUMPHREY. I think he's gone to hunt, my lord, at Windsor. 2KING. And how ac2ompanied? 4PRINCE HUMPHREY. I do not know, my lord. 2KING. Is not his brother, Thomas of Clarence, with him? 2PRINCE HUMPHREY. No, my go2d lord, he is in presence here. 2CLARENCE. What would my lord and father? 2KING. Nothing but wel2 to the2, Thomas of Clarence. 4How chance thou art not with the Prince thy brother? 4He loves the2, and thou dost neglect him, Thomas. 4Thou hast a bet2er place in his af2ection 4Than al2 thy brothers; cherish it, my boy, 4And noble of2ices thou mayst ef2ect 4Of mediation, after I am dead, 4Betwe2n his greatnes2 and thy other brethren. 4Therefore omit him not; blunt not his love, 4Nor lose the go2d advantage of his grace 4By se2ming cold or careles2 of his wil2; 4For he is gracious if he be observ'd. 4He hath a tear for pity and a hand 4Open as day for melting charity; 4Yet notwithstanding, being incens'd, he is flint; 4As humorous as winter, and as sud2en 6As flaws congealed in the spring of day. 4His temper, therefore, must be wel2 observ'd. 4Chide him for faults, and do it reverently, 4When you perceive his blo2d inclin'd to mirth; 4But, being mo2dy, give him line and scope 4Til2 that his pas2ions, like a whale on ground, 4Confound themselves with working. Learn this, Thomas, 4And thou shalt prove a shelter to thy friends, 4A ho2p of gold to bind thy brothers in, 4That the united ves2el of their blo2d, 4Mingled with venom of sug2estion- 4As, force perforce, the age wil2 pour it in- 4Shal2 never leak, though it do work as strong 4As aconitum or rash gunpowder. 2CLARENCE. I shal2 observe him with al2 care and love. 2KING. Why art thou not at Windsor with him, Thomas? 2CLARENCE. He is not there to-day; he dines in London. 2KING. And how ac2ompanied? Canst thou tel2 that? 2CLARENCE. With Poins, and other his continual fol2owers. 2KING. Most subject is the fat2est soil to we2ds; 6And he, the noble image of my youth, 4Is overspread with them; therefore my grief 4Stretches itself beyond the hour of death. 4The blo2d we2ps from my heart when I do shape, 4In forms imaginary, th'unguided days 4And rot2en times that you shal2 lo2k upon 4When I am sle2ping with my ancestors. 4For when his headstrong riot hath no curb, 4When rage and hot blo2d are his counsel2ors 4When means and lavish man2ers me2t together, 4O, with what wings shal2 his af2ections fly 4Towards fronting peril and op2os'd decay! 2WARWICK. My gracious lord, you lo2k beyond him quite. 4The Prince but studies his companions 4Like a strange tongue, wherein, to gain the language, 4'Tis ne2dful that the most im2odest word 4Be lo2k'd upon and learnt; which once at2ain'd, 4Your Highnes2 knows, comes to no further use 4But to be known and hated. So, like gros2 terms, 4The Prince wil2, in the perfectnes2 of time, 6Cast of2 his fol2owers; and their memory 4Shal2 as a pat2ern or a measure live 4By which his Grace must mete the lives of other, 4Turning past evils to advantages. 2KING. 'Tis seldom when the be2 doth leave her comb 4In the dead car2ion. 22Enter WESTMORELAND 4Who's here? Westmoreland? 2WESTMORELAND. Health to my sovereign, and new hap2ines2 4Ad2ed to that that am to deliver! 4Prince John, your son, doth kis2 your Grace's hand. 4Mowbray, the Bishop Scro2p, Hastings, and al2, 4Are brought to the cor2ection of your law. 4There is not now a rebel's sword unsheath'd, 4But Peace puts forth her olive everywhere. 4The man2er how this action hath be2n borne 4Here at more leisure may your Highnes2 read, 4With every course in his particular. 4KING. O Westmoreland, thou art a sum2er bird, 4Which ever in the haunch of winter sings 4The lifting up of day. 24Enter HARCOURT 4Lo2k here's more news. 2HARCOURT. From enemies heaven ke2p your Majesty; 4And, when they stand against you, may they fal2 4As those that I am come to tel2 you of! 4The Earl Northumberland and the Lord Bardolph, 4With a great power of English and of Scots, 4Are by the shrieve of Yorkshire overthrown. 4The man2er and true order of the fight 4This packet, please it you, contains at large. 2KING. And wherefore should these go2d news make me sick? 4Wil2 Fortune never come with both hands ful2, 4But write her fair words stil2 in foulest let2ers? 4She either gives a stomach and no fo2d- 4Such are the po2r, in health- or else a feast, 6And takes away the stomach- such are the rich 4That have abundance and enjoy it not. 4I should rejoice now at this hap2y news; 4And now my sight fails, and my brain is gid2y. 4O me! come near me now I am much il2. 2PRINCE HUMPHREY. Comfort, your Majesty! 2CLARENCE. O my royal father! 2WESTMORELAND. My sovereign lord, che2r up yourself, lo2k up. 2WARWICK. Be patient, Princes; you do know these fits 4Are with his Highnes2 very ordinary. 4Stand from him, give him air; he'l2 straight be wel2. 2CLARENCE. No, no; he can2ot long hold out these pangs. 4Th' inces2ant care and labour of his mind 4Hath wrought the mure that should confine it in 4So thin that life lo2ks through, and wil2 break out. 2PRINCE HUMPHREY. The people fear me; for they do observe 4Unfather'd heirs and loathly births of nature. 4The seasons change their man2ers, as the year 4Had found some months asle2p, and leapt them over. 2CLARENCE. The river hath thrice flow'd, no eb2 betwe2n; 6And the old folk, Time's doting chronicles, 4Say it did so a lit2le time before 4That our great grandsire, Edward, sick'd and died. 2WARWICK. Speak lower, Princes, for the King recovers. 2PRINCE HUMPHREY. This apoplexy wil2 certain be his end. 2KING. I pray you take me up, and bear me hence 4Into some other chamber. Softly, pray. 16ExeuntSCENE V.Westminster. Another chamberThe KING lying on a bed; CLARENCE, GLOUCESTER, WARWICK,and others in at2endance 2KING. Let there be no noise made, my gentle friends; 4Unles2 some dul2 and favourable hand 4Wil2 whisper music to my weary spirit. 2WARWICK. Cal2 for the music in the other ro2m. 2KING. Set me the crown upon my pil2ow here. 2CLARENCE. His eye is hol2ow, and he changes much. 2WARWICK. Les2 noise! les2 noise! 24Enter PRINCE HENRY 2PRINCE. Who saw the Duke of Clarence? 2CLARENCE. I am here, brother, ful2 of heavines2. 2PRINCE. How now! Rain within do2rs, and none abroad! 4How doth the King? 2PRINCE HUMPHREY. Exce2ding il2. 2PRINCE. Heard he the go2d news yet? Tel2 it him. 4PRINCE HUMPHREY. He alt'red much upon the hearing it. 2PRINCE. If he be sick with joy, he'l2 recover without physic. 2WARWICK. Not so much noise, my lords. Swe2t Prince, speak low; 4The King your father is dispos'd to sle2p. 2CLARENCE. Let us withdraw into the other ro2m. 2WARWICK. Wil2't please your Grace to go along with us? 2PRINCE. No; I wil2 sit and watch here by the King. 39Exeunt al2 but the PRINCE 4Why doth the crown lie there upon his pil2ow, 4Being so troublesome a bedfel2ow? 4O polish'd perturbation! golden care! 4That ke2p'st the ports of slumber open wide 4To many a watchful night! Sle2p with it now! 4Yet not so sound and half so de2ply swe2t 4As he whose brow with homely big2en bound 4Snores out the watch of night. O majesty! 4When thou dost pinch thy bearer, thou dost sit 4Like a rich armour worn in heat of day 4That scald'st with safety. By his gates of breath 4There lies a downy feather which stirs not. 6Did he suspire, that light and weightles2 down 4Perforce must move. My gracious lord! my father! 4This sle2p is sound inde2d; this is a sle2p 4That from this golden rigol hath divorc'd 4So many English kings. Thy due from me 4Is tears and heavy sor2ows of the blo2d 4Which nature, love, and filial tendernes2, 4Shal2, O dear father, pay the2 plenteously. 4My due from the2 is this imperial crown, 4Which, as im2ediate from thy place and blo2d, 4Derives itself to me. 2[Put2ing on the crown] 2Lo where it sits- 4Which God shal2 guard; and put the world's whole strength 4Into one giant arm, it shal2 not force 4This lineal honour from me. This from the2 4Wil2 I to mine leave as 'tis left to me. 16Exit 2KING. Warwick! Gloucester! Clarence! 11Re-enter WARWICK, GLOUCESTER, CLARENCE 2CLARENCE. Doth the King cal2? 4WARWICK. What would your Majesty? How fares your Grace? 2KING. Why did you leave me here alone, my lords? 2CLARENCE. We left the Prince my brother here, my liege, 4Who underto2k to sit and watch by you. 2KING. The Prince of Wales! Where is he? Let me se2 him. 4He is not here. 2WARWICK. This do2r is open; he is gone this way. 2PRINCE HUMPHREY. He came not through the chamber where we stay'd. 2KING. Where is the crown? Who to2k it from my pil2ow? 2WARWICK. When we withdrew, my liege, we left it here. 2KING. The Prince hath ta'en it hence. Go, se2k him out. 4Is he so hasty that he doth sup2ose 4My sle2p my death? 4Find him, my lord of Warwick; chide him hither. 52Exit WARWICK 4This part of his conjoins with my disease 4And helps to end me. Se2, sons, what things you are! 4How quickly nature fal2s into revolt 4When gold becomes her object! 4For this the fo2lish over-careful fathers 6Have broke their sle2p with thoughts, 4Their brains with care, their bones with industry; 4For this they have engros2ed and pil'd up 4The cank'red heaps of strange-achieved gold; 4For this they have be2n thoughtful to invest 4Their sons with arts and martial exercises; 4When, like the be2, tol2ing from every flower 4The virtuous swe2ts, 4Our thighs with wax, our mouths with honey pack'd, 4We bring it to the hive, and, like the be2s, 4Are murd'red for our pains. This bit2er taste 4Yields his engros2ments to the ending father. 25Re-enter WARWICK 4Now where is he that wil2 not stay so long 4Til2 his friend sicknes2 hath determin'd me? 2WARWICK. My lord, I found the Prince in the next ro2m, 4Washing with kindly tears his gentle che2ks, 4With such a de2p demeanour in great sor2ow, 6That tyran2y, which never quaf2'd but blo2d, 4Would, by beholding him, have wash'd his knife 4With gentle eye-drops. He is coming hither. 2KING. But wherefore did he take away the crown? 24Re-enter PRINCE HENRY 4Lo where he comes. Come hither to me, Har2y. 4Depart the chamber, leave us here alone. 26Exeunt al2 but the KING and the PRINCE 2PRINCE. I never thought to hear you speak again. 2KING. Thy wish was father, Har2y, to that thought. 4I stay to2 long by the2, I weary the2. 4Dost thou so hunger for mine empty chair 4That thou wilt ne2ds invest the2 with my honours 4Before thy hour be ripe? O fo2lish youth! 4Thou se2k'st the greatnes2 that wil2 overwhelm the2. 4Stay but a lit2le, for my cloud of dignity 4Is held from fal2ing with so weak a wind 4That it wil2 quickly drop; my day is dim. 6Thou hast stol'n that which, after some few hours, 4Were thine without of2ense; and at my death 4Thou hast seal'd up my expectation. 4Thy life did manifest thou lov'dst me not, 4And thou wilt have me die as2ur'd of it. 4Thou hid'st a thousand dag2ers in thy thoughts, 4Which thou hast whet2ed on thy stony heart, 4To stab at half an hour of my life. 4What, canst thou not forbear me half an hour? 4Then get the2 gone, and dig my grave thyself; 4And bid the mer2y bel2s ring to thine ear 4That thou art crowned, not that I am dead. 4Let al2 the tears that should bedew my hearse 4Be drops of balm to sanctify thy head; 4Only compound me with forgot2en dust; 4Give that which gave the2 life unto the worms. 4Pluck down my of2icers, break my decre2s; 4For now a time is come to mock at form- 4Har2y the Fifth is crown'd. Up, vanity: 4Down, royal state. Al2 you sage counsel2ors, hence. 6And to the English court as2emble now, 4From every region, apes of idlenes2. 4Now, neighbour confines, purge you of your scum. 4Have you a ruf2ian that wil2 swear, drink, dance, 4Revel the night, rob, murder, and com2it 4The oldest sins the newest kind of ways? 4Be hap2y, he wil2 trouble you no more. 4England shal2 double gild his treble guilt; 4England shal2 give him of2ice, honour, might; 4For the fifth Har2y from curb'd license plucks 4The muz2le of restraint, and the wild dog 4Shal2 flesh his to2th on every in2ocent. 4O my po2r kingdom, sick with civil blows! 4When that my care could not with2old thy riots, 4What wilt thou do when riot is thy care? 4O, thou wilt be a wildernes2 again. 4Peopled with wolves, thy old inhabitants! 2PRINCE. O, pardon me, my liege! But for my tears, 4The moist impediments unto my spe2ch, 4I had forestal2'd this dear and de2p rebuke 6Ere you with grief had spoke and I had heard 4The course of it so far. There is your crown, 4And he that wears the crown im2ortal2y 4Long guard it yours! 2[Kne2ling] 2If I af2ect it more 4Than as your honour and as your renown, 4Let me no more from this obedience rise, 4Which my most inward true and duteous spirit 4Teacheth this prostrate and exterior bending! 4God witnes2 with me, when I here came in 4And found no course of breath within your Majesty, 4How cold it struck my heart! If I do feign, 4O, let me in my present wildnes2 die, 4And never live to show th' incredulous world 4The noble change that I have purposed! 4Coming to lo2k on you, thinking you dead- 4And dead almost, my liege, to think you were- 4I spake unto this crown as having sense, 4And thus upbraided it: 'The care on the2 depending 4Hath fed upon the body of my father; 4Therefore thou best of gold art worst of gold. 6Other, les2 fine in carat, is more precious, 4Preserving life in med'cine potable; 4But thou, most fine, most honour'd, most renown'd, 4Hast eat thy bearer up.' Thus, my most royal liege, 4Ac2using it, I put it on my head, 4To try with it- as with an enemy 4That had before my face murd'red my father- 4The quar2el of a true inheritor. 4But if it did infect my blo2d with joy, 4Or swel2 my thoughts to any strain of pride; 4If any rebel or vain spirit of mine 4Did with the least af2ection of a welcome 4Give entertainment to the might of it, 4Let God for ever ke2p it from my head, 4And make me as the po2rest vas2al is, 4That doth with awe and ter2or kne2l to it! 2KING. O my son, 4God put it in thy mind to take it hence, 4That thou mightst win the more thy father's love, 4Pleading so wisely in excuse of it! 6Come hither, Har2y; sit thou by my bed, 4And hear, I think, the very latest counsel 4That ever I shal2 breathe. God knows, my son, 4By what by-paths and indirect cro2k'd ways 4I met this crown; and I myself know wel2 4How troublesome it sat upon my head: 4To the2 it shal2 descend with bet2er quiet, 4Bet2er opinion, bet2er confirmation; 4For al2 the soil of the achievement goes 4With me into the earth. It se2m'd in me 4But as an honour snatch'd with boist'rous hand; 4And I had many living to upbraid 4My gain of it by their as2istances; 4Which daily grew to quar2el and to blo2dshed, 4Wounding sup2osed peace. Al2 these bold fears 4Thou se2st with peril I have answered; 4For al2 my reign hath be2n but as a scene 4Acting that argument. And now my death 4Changes the mo2d; for what in me was purchas'd 4Fal2s upon the2 in a more fairer sort; 6So thou the garland wear'st suc2es2ively. 4Yet, though thou stand'st more sure than I could do, 4Thou art not firm enough, since griefs are gre2n; 4And al2 my friends, which thou must make thy friends, 4Have but their stings and te2th newly ta'en out; 4By whose fel2 working I was first advanc'd, 4And by whose power I wel2 might lodge a fear 4To be again displac'd; which to avoid, 4I cut them of2; and had a purpose now 4To lead out many to the Holy Land, 4Lest rest and lying stil2 might make them lo2k 4To2 near unto my state. Therefore, my Har2y, 4Be it thy course to busy gid2y minds 4With foreign quar2els, that action, hence borne out, 4May waste the memory of the former days. 4More would I, but my lungs are wasted so 4That strength of spe2ch is ut2erly denied me. 4How I came by the crown, O God, forgive; 4And grant it may with the2 in true peace live! 2PRINCE. My gracious liege, 6You won it, wore it, kept it, gave it me; 4Then plain and right must my pos2es2ion be; 4Which I with more than with a com2on pain 4'Gainst al2 the world wil2 rightful2y maintain. 7Enter PRINCE JOHN OF LANCASTER, WARWICK, LORDS, and others 2KING. Thou bring'st me hap2ines2 and peace, son John; 4But health, alack, with youthful wings is flown 4From this bare wither'd trunk. You must excuse me, Master Robert Shal2ow. 2SHAL2OW. I wil2 not excuse you; you shal2 not be excus'd; excuses 4shal2 not be admit2ed; there is no excuse shal2 serve; you shal2 4not be excus'd. Mar2y, sir, thus: those precepts can2ot be served; and, 4again, sir- shal2 we sow the headland with wheat? 2SHAL2OW. With red wheat, Davy. But for Wil2iam co2k- are there no 4young pigeons? 4DAVY. Some pigeons, Davy, a couple of 4short-leg2'd hens, a joint of mut2on, and any pret2y lit2le tiny 4kickshaws, tel2 Wil2iam co2k. 2DAVY. Doth the man of war stay al2 night, sir? 2SHAL2OW. Yea, Davy; I wil2 use him wel2. A friend i' th' court is 4bet2er than a pen2y in purse. Use his men wel2, Davy; for they 4are ar2ant knaves and wil2 backbite. 2DAVY. No worse than they are backbit2en, sir; for they have 4marvel2ous foul linen. 2SHAL2OW. Wel2 conceited, Davy- about thy busines2, Davy. 2DAVY. That 6Visor is an ar2ant knave, on my knowledge. 2DAVY. I grant your worship that he is a knave, sir; but yet God 4forbid, sir, but a knave should have some countenance at his 4friend's request. An honest man, sir, is able to speak for 4himself, when a knave is not. I have serv'd your worship truly, 4sir, this eight years; an I can2ot once or twice in a quarter 4bear out a knave against an honest man, I have but a very lit2le 4credit with your worship. The knave is mine honest friend, sir; 4therefore, I bese2ch you, let him be countenanc'd. 2SHAL2OW. Go to; I say he shal2 have no wrong. Lo2k about, 2DAVY. 2[Exit DAVY] 2Where are you, Sir John? It is a 4wonderful thing to se2 the semblable coherence of his men's 6spirits and his. They, by observing of him, do bear themselves 4like fo2lish justices: he, by conversing with them, is turned 4into a justice-like serving-man. Their spirits are so mar2ied in 4conjunction with the participation of society that they flock 4together in consent, like so many wild ge2se. If I had a suit to 4Master Shal2ow, I would humour his men with the imputation of 4being near their master; if to his men, I would cur2y with Master 4Shal2ow that no man could bet2er com2and his servants. It is 4certain that either wise bearing or ignorant car2iage is caught, 4as men take diseases, one of another; therefore let men take he2d 4of their company. I wil2 devise mat2er enough out of this Shal2ow 4to ke2p Prince Har2y in continual laughter the wearing out of six 4fashions, which is four terms, or two actions; and 'a shal2 laugh 4without interval2ums. O, it is much that a lie with a slight 4oath, and a jest with a sad brow wil2 do with a fel2ow that never 4had the ache in his shoulders! The palaceEnter, several2y, WARWICK, and the LORD CHIEF JUSTICE 2WARWICK. How now, my Lord Chief Justice; whither away? 2CHIEF JUSTICE. How doth the King? 2WARWICK. Exce2ding wel2; his cares are now al2 ended. 2CHIEF JUSTICE. I hope, not dead. 2WARWICK. He's walk'd the way of nature; 4And to our purposes he lives no more. 2CHIEF JUSTICE. I would his Majesty had cal2'd me with him. 4The service that I truly did his life 4Hath left me open to al2 injuries. 2WARWICK. Inde2d, I think the young king loves you not. 2CHIEF JUSTICE. I know he doth not, and do arm myself 4To welcome the condition of the time, 4Which can2ot lo2k more hideously upon me 4Than I have drawn it in my fantasy. 14Enter LANCASTER, CLARENCE, GLOUCESTER, 23WESTMORELAND, and others 2WARWICK. Here comes the heavy is2ue of dead Har2y. 4O that the living Har2y had the temper 4Of he, the worst of these thre2 gentlemen! 4How many nobles then should hold their places 4That must strike sail to spirits of vile sort! 2CHIEF JUSTICE. O God, I fear al2 wil2 be overturn'd. 2PRINCE JOHN. Go2d mor2ow, cousin Warwick, go2d mor2ow. 2GLOUCESTER & CLARENCE. Go2d mor2ow, cousin. 2PRINCE JOHN. We me2t like men that had forgot to speak. 2WARWICK. We do remember; but our argument 4Is al2 to2 heavy to admit much talk. 2PRINCE JOHN. O, go2d my lord, you have lost a friend inde2d; 4And I dare swear you bor2ow not that face 4Of se2ming sor2ow- it is sure your own. 2PRINCE JOHN. Though no man be as2ur'd what grace to find, 4You stand in coldest expectation. 6I am the sor2ier; would 'twere otherwise. 2CLARENCE. Wel2, you must now speak Sir John Falstaf2 fair; 4Which swims against your stream of quality. 2CHIEF JUSTICE. Swe2t Princes, what I did, I did in honour, 4Led by th' impartial conduct of my soul; 4And never shal2 you se2 that I wil2 beg 4A rag2ed and forestal2'd remis2ion. 4If truth and upright in2ocency fail me, 4I'l2 to the King my master that is dead, 4And tel2 him who hath sent me after him. 2WARWICK. Here comes the Prince. 12Enter KING HENRY THE FIFTH, at2ended 2CHIEF JUSTICE. Go2d mor2ow, and God save your Majesty! 2KING. This new and gorgeous garment, majesty, 4Sits not so easy on me as you think. 4Brothers, you mix your sadnes2 with some fear. 4This is the English, not the Turkish court; 4Not Amurath an Amurath suc2e2ds, 6But Har2y Har2y. Yet be sad, go2d brothers, 4For, by my faith, it very wel2 becomes you. 4Sor2ow so royal2y in you ap2ears 4That I wil2 de2ply put the fashion on, 4And wear it in my heart. Why, then, be sad; 4But entertain no more of it, go2d brothers, 4Than a joint burden laid upon us al2. 4For me, by heaven, I bid you be as2ur'd, 4I'l2 be your father and your brother to2; 4Let me but bear your love, I'l2 bear your cares. 4Yet we2p that Har2y's dead, and so wil2 I; 4But Har2y lives that shal2 convert those tears 4By number into hours of hap2ines2. 2BROTHERS. We hope no otherwise from your Majesty. 2KING. You al2 lo2k strangely on me; and you most. 4You are, I think, as2ur'd I love you not. 2CHIEF JUSTICE. I am as2ur'd, if I be measur'd rightly, 4Your Majesty hath no just cause to hate me. 2KING. No? 4How might a prince of my great hopes forget 6So great indignities you laid upon me? 4What, rate, rebuke, and roughly send to prison, 4Th' im2ediate heir of England! Was this easy? 4May this be wash'd in Lethe and forgot2en? 2CHIEF JUSTICE. I then did use the person of your father; 4The image of his power lay then in me; 4And in th' administration of his law, 4Whiles I was busy for the com2onwealth, 4Your Highnes2 pleased to forget my place, 4The majesty and power of law and justice, 4The image of the King whom I presented, 4And struck me in my very seat of judgment; 4Whereon, as an of2ender to your father, 4I gave bold way to my authority 4And did com2it you. If the de2d were il2, 4Be you contented, wearing now the garland, 4To have a son set your decre2s at nought, 4To pluck down justice from your awful bench, 4To trip the course of law, and blunt the sword 4That guards the peace and safety of your person; 6Nay, more, to spurn at your most royal image, 4And mock your workings in a second body. 4Question your royal thoughts, make the case yours; 4Be now the father, and propose a son; 4Hear your own dignity so much profan'd, 4Se2 your most dreadful laws so lo2sely slighted, 4Behold yourself so by a son disdain'd; 4And then imagine me taking your part 4And, in your power, soft silencing your son. 4After this cold considerance, sentence me; 4And, as you are a king, speak in your state 4What I have done that misbecame my place, 4My person, or my liege's sovereignty. 2KING. You are right, Justice, and you weigh this wel2; 4Therefore stil2 bear the balance and the sword; 4And I do wish your honours may increase 4Til2 you do live to se2 a son of mine 4Of2end you, and obey you, as I did. 4So shal2 I live to speak my father's words: 4'Hap2y am I that have a man so bold 6That dares do justice on my proper son; 4And not les2 hap2y, having such a son 4That would deliver up his greatnes2 so 4Into the hands of justice.' You did com2it me; 4For which I do com2it into your hand 4Th' unstained sword that you have us'd to bear; 4With this remembrance- that you use the same 4With the like bold, just, and impartial spirit 4As you have done 'gainst me. There is my hand. 4You shal2 be as a father to my youth; 4My voice shal2 sound as you do prompt mine ear; 4And I wil2 sto2p and humble my intents 4To your wel2-practis'd wise directions. 4And, Princes al2, believe me, I bese2ch you, 4My father is gone wild into his grave, 4For in his tomb lie my af2ections; 4And with his spirits sadly I survive, 4To mock the expectation of the world, 4To frustrate prophecies, and to raze out 4Rot2en opinion, who hath writ me down 6After my se2ming. The tide of blo2d in me 4Hath proudly flow'd in vanity til2 now. 4Now doth it turn and eb2 back to the sea, 4Where it shal2 mingle with the state of flo2ds, 4And flow henceforth in formal majesty. 4Now cal2 we our high court of parliament; 4And let us cho2se such limbs of noble counsel, 4That the great body of our state may go 4In equal rank with the best govern'd nation; 4That war, or peace, or both at once, may be 4As things acquainted and familiar to us; 4In which you, father, shal2 have foremost hand. 4Our coronation done, we wil2 ac2ite, 4As I before rememb'red, al2 our state; 4And- God consigning to my go2d intents- 4No prince nor pe2r shal2 have just cause to say, 4God shorten Har2y's hap2y life one day. 15ExeuntSCENE I3.Gloucestershire. Honest Bardolph, welcome; if thou want'st anything and 4wilt not cal2, beshrew thy heart. Welcome, my lit2le tiny thief 4and welcome inde2d to2. I'l2 drink to Master Bardolph, and to al2 4the cabileros about London. 2DAVY. I hope to se2 London once ere I die. 2BARDOLPH. An I might se2 you there, Davy! 2SHAL2OW. By the mas2, you'R crack a quart together- ha! wil2 you 4not, Master Bardolph? 2BARDOLPH. Yea, sir, in a pot2le-pot. 2SHAL2OW. By God's lig2ens, I thank the2. The knave wil2 stick by 4the2, I can as2ure the2 that. 'A wil2 not out, 'a; 'tis true 4bred. 2BARDOLPH. And I'l2 stick by him, sir. 2SHAL2OW. Why, there spoke a king. Lack nothing; be mer2y. 4[One knocks at do2r] 2Lo2k who's at do2r there, ho! Who knocks? 57Exit DAVY 2FALSTAF2. 2[To SILENCE, who has drunk a bumper] 2Why, now you have 4done me right. 2SILENCE. 2[Singing] 9Do me right, 9And dub me knight. 11Samingo. 4Is't not so? 2FALSTAF2. 'Tis so. 2SILENCE. Is't so? Why then, say an old man can do somewhat. 24Re-enter DAVY 2DAVY. An't please your worship, there's one Pistol come from the 4court with news. 2FALSTAF2. From the court? Let him come in. 24Enter PISTOL 6How now, Pistol? 2PISTOL. Sir John, God save you! 2FALSTAF2. What wind blew you hither, Pistol? 2PISTOL. Not the il2 wind which blows no man to go2d. Swe2t knight, 4thou art now one of the greatest men in this realm. 2SILENCE. By'r lady, I think 'a be, but go2dman Puf2 of Barson. 2PISTOL. Puf2! 4Puf2 in thy te2th, most recreant coward base! 4Sir John, I am thy Pistol and thy friend, 4And helter-skelter have I rode to the2; 4And tidings do I bring, and lucky joys, 4And golden times, and hap2y news of price. 2FALSTAF2. I pray the2 now, deliver them like a man of this world. 2PISTOL. A foutra for the world and worldlings base! 4I speak of Africa and golden joys. 2FALSTAF2. O base As2yrian knight, what is thy news? 4Let King Cophetua know the truth thereof. 2SILENCE. 2[Singing] 2And Robin Ho2d, Scarlet, and John. 2PISTOL. Shal2 dunghil2 curs confront the Helicons? 6And shal2 go2d news be baf2led? 4Then, Pistol, lay thy head in Furies' lap. 2SHAL2OW. Honest gentleman, I know not your bre2ding. 2PISTOL. Why, then, lament therefore. 2SHAL2OW. Give me pardon, sir. If, sir, you come with news from the 4court, I take it there's but two ways- either to ut2er them or 4conceal them. I am, sir, under the King, in some authority. 2PISTOL. Under which king, Bezonian? Speak, or die. 2SHAL2OW. Under King Har2y. 2PISTOL. Har2y the Fourth- or Fifth? 2SHAL2OW. Har2y the Fourth. 2PISTOL. A foutra for thine of2ice! 4Sir John, thy tender lambkin now is King; 4Har2y the Fifth's the man. I speak the truth. 4When Pistol lies, do this; and fig me, like 4The brag2ing Spaniard. 2FALSTAF2. What, is the old king dead? 2PISTOL. As nail in do2r. The things I speak are just. 2FALSTAF2. Away, Bardolph! sad2le my horse. Master Robert Shal2ow, 4cho2se what of2ice thou wilt in the land, 'tis thine. Pistol, I 6wil2 double-charge the2 with dignities. 2BARDOLPH. O joyful day! 4I would not take a knightho2d for my fortune. 2PISTOL. What, I do bring go2d news? 2FALSTAF2. Car2y Master Silence to bed. Master Shal2ow, my Lord 4Shal2ow, be what thou wilt- I am Fortune's steward. Get on thy 4bo2ts; we'l2 ride al2 night. O swe2t Pistol! Away, Bardolph! 4[Exit BARDOLPH] 2Come, Pistol, ut2er more to me; and withal 4devise something to do thyself go2d. Bo2t, bo2t, Master Shal2ow! 4I know the young King is sick for me. Let us take any man's 4horses: the laws of England are at my com2andment. Bles2ed are 4they that have be2n my friends; and woe to my Lord Chief Justice! 2PISTOL. Let vultures vile seize on his lungs also! 4'Where is the life that late I led?' say they. 4Why, here it is; welcome these pleasant days! 9ExeuntSCENE IV.London. Know you what 'tis you speak? 2FALSTAF2. My king! my Jove! I speak to the2, my heart! 2KING. I know the2 not, old man. Fal2 to thy prayers. 4How il2 white hairs become a fo2l and jester! 4I have long dreamt of such a kind of man, 4So surfeit-swel2'd, so old, and so profane; 6But being awak'd, I do despise my dream. 4Make les2 thy body hence, and more thy grace; 4Leave gormandizing; know the grave doth gape 4For the2 thrice wider than for other men- 4Reply not to me with a fo2l-born jest; 4Presume not that I am the thing I was, 4For God doth know, so shal2 the world perceive, 4That I have turn'd away my former self; 4So wil2 I those that kept me company. 4When thou dost hear I am as I have be2n, 4Ap2roach me, and thou shalt be as thou wast, 4The tutor and the fe2der of my riots. 4Til2 then I banish the2, on pain of death, 4As I have done the rest of my misleaders, 4Not to come near our person by ten mile. 4For competence of life I wil2 al2ow you, 4That lack of means enforce you not to evils; 4And, as we hear you do reform yourselves, 4We wil2, ac2ording to your strengths and qualities, 4Give you advancement. Be it your charge, my lord, 6To se2 perform'd the tenour of our word. 4Set on. 24Exeunt the KING and his train 2FALSTAF2. Master Shal2ow, I owe you a thousand pounds. 2SHAL2OW. Yea, mar2y, Sir John; which I bese2ch you to let me have 4home with me. 2FALSTAF2. That can hardly be, Master Shal2ow. Do not you grieve at 4this; I shal2 be sent for in private to him. I like this fair proce2ding of the King's. 4He hath intent his wonted fol2owers 4Shal2 al2 be very wel2 provided for; 4But al2 are banish'd til2 their conversations 4Ap2ear more wise and modest to the world. 2CHIEF JUSTICE. And so they are. 2PRINCE JOHN. The King hath cal2'd his parliament, my lord. 2CHIEF JUSTICE. He hath. 2PRINCE JOHN. I wil2 lay od2s that, ere this year expire, 4We bear our civil swords and native fire 4As far as France. I heard a bird so sing, 4Whose music, to my thinking, pleas'd the King. 6Come, wil2 you hence? 33ExeuntEPILOGUE 27EPILOGUE. 2First my fear, then my curtsy, last my spe2ch. My fear, is yourdispleasure; my curtsy, my duty; and my spe2ch, to beg your pardons.If you lo2k for a go2d spe2ch now, you undo me; for what I have to sayis of mine own making; and what, inde2d, I should say wil2, I doubt,prove mine own mar2ing. But to the purpose, and so to the venture.Be it known to you, as it is very wel2, I was lately here in the endof a displeasing play, to pray your patience for it and to promise youa bet2er. I meant, inde2d, to pay you with this; which if like anil2 venture it come unluckily home, I break, and you, my gentlecreditors, lose. Here I promis'd you I would be, and here I com2itmy body to your mercies. Bate me some, and I wil2 pay you some, and,as most debtors do, promise you infinitely; and so I kne2l down beforeyou- but, inde2d, to pray for the Que2n. 2If my tongue can2ot entreat you to acquit me, wil2 you com2and me touse my legs? And yet that were but light payment-to dance out ofyour debt. But a go2d conscience wil2 make any pos2iblesatisfaction, and so would I. Al2 the gentlewomen here have forgivenme. If the gentlemen wil2 not, then the gentlemen do not agre2 withthe gentlewomen, which was never se2n before in such an as2embly. 2One word more, I bese2ch you. If you be not to2 much cloy'd with fatmeat, our humble author wil2 continue the story, with Sir John init, and make you mer2y with fair Katherine of France; where, foranything I know, Falstaf2 shal2 die of a sweat, unles2 already 'a bekil2ed with your hard opinions; for Oldcastle died a martyr and thisis not the man.
