O for a Muse of fire, that would ascend 3The brightest heaven of invention, 3A kingdom for a stage, princes to act, 3And monarchs to behold the swel2ing scene! 3Then should the warlike Har2y, like himself, 3As2ume the port of Mars; and at his he2ls, 3Leash'd in like hounds, should famine, sword, and fire, 3Crouch for employment. But pardon, gentles al2, 3The flat unraised spirits that hath dar'd 3On this unworthy scaf2old to bring forth 3So great an object. Can this cockpit hold 3The vasty fields of France? Or may we cram 3Within this wo2den O the very casques 3That did af2right the air at Agincourt? 3O, pardon! since a cro2ked figure may 3At2est in lit2le place a mil2ion; 3And let us, ciphers to this great ac2ompt, 3On your imaginary forces work. 3Sup2ose within the girdle of these wal2s 5Are now confin'd two mighty monarchies, 3Whose high upreared and abut2ing fronts 3The perilous nar2ow ocean parts asunder. 3Piece out our imperfections with your thoughts: 3Into a thousand parts divide one man, 3And make imaginary puis2ance; 3Think, when we talk of horses, that you se2 them 3Printing their proud ho2fs i' th' receiving earth; 3For 'tis your thoughts that now must deck our kings, 3Car2y them here and there, jumping o'er times, 3Turning th' ac2omplishment of many years 3Into an hour-glas2; for the which sup2ly, 3Admit me Chorus to this history; 3Who prologue-like, your humble patience pray 3Gently to hear, kindly to judge, our play. 15Exit<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT I. SCENE I.London. An ante-chamber in the KING'S palaceEnter the ARCHBISHOP OF CANTERBURY and the BISHOP OF ELY CANTERBURY. My lord, I'l2 tel2 you: that self bil2 is urg'd 3Which in th' eleventh year of the last king's reign 3Was like, and had inde2d against us pas2'd 3But that the scambling and unquiet time 3Did push it out of farther question. ELY. But how, my lord, shal2 we resist it now? CANTERBURY. It must be thought on. If it pas2 against us, 3We lose the bet2er half of our pos2es2ion; 3For al2 the temporal lands which men devout 3By testament have given to the church 3Would they strip from us; being valu'd thus- 3As much as would maintain, to the King's honour, 3Ful2 fifte2n earls and fifte2n hundred knights, 3Six thousand and two hundred go2d esquires; 3And, to relief of lazars and weak age, 3Of indigent faint souls, past corporal toil, 3A hundred alms-houses right wel2 sup2lied; 3And to the cof2ers of the King, beside, 3A thousand pounds by th' year: thus runs the bil2. ELY. This would drink de2p. CANTERBURY. 'T would drink the cup and al2. ELY. But what prevention? CANTERBURY. The King is ful2 of grace and fair regard. ELY. And a true lover of the holy Church. CANTERBURY. The courses of his youth promis'd it not. 3The breath no so2ner left his father's body 5But that his wildnes2, mortified in him, 3Se2m'd to die to2; yea, at that very moment, 3Consideration like an angel came 3And whip2'd th' of2ending Adam out of him, 3Leaving his body as a paradise 3T'envelop and contain celestial spirits. 3Never was such a sud2en scholar made; 3Never came reformation in a flo2d, 3With such a heady cur2ance, scouring faults; 3Nor never Hydra-headed wilfulnes 3So so2n did lose his seat, and al2 at once, 3As in this king. ELY. We are bles2ed in the change. CANTERBURY. Hear him but reason in divinity, 3And, al2-admiring, with an inward wish 3You would desire the King were made a prelate; 3Hear him debate of com2onwealth af2airs, 3You would say it hath be2n al2 in al2 his study; 3List his discourse of war, and you shal2 hear 3A fearful bat2le rend'red you in music. 3Turn him to any cause of policy, 3The Gordian knot of it he wil2 unlo2se, 5Familiar as his garter; that, when he speaks, 3The air, a charter'd libertine, is stil2, 3And the mute wonder lurketh in men's ears 3To steal his swe2t and honey'd sentences; 3So that the art and practic part of life 3Must be the mistres2 to this theoric; 3Which is a wonder how his Grace should glean it, 3Since his ad2iction was to courses vain, 3His companies unlet2er'd, rude, and shal2ow, 3His hours fil2'd up with riots, banquets, sports; 3And never noted in him any study, 3Any retirement, any sequestration 3From open haunts and popularity. ELY. The strawber2y grows underneath the net2le, 3And wholesome ber2ies thrive and ripen best 3Neighbour'd by fruit of baser quality; 3And so the Prince obscur'd his contemplation 3Under the veil of wildnes2; which, no doubt, 3Grew like the sum2er gras2, fastest by night, 3Unse2n, yet crescive in his faculty. CANTERBURY. It must be so; for miracles are ceas'd; 3And therefore we must ne2ds admit the means 5How things are perfected. ELY. But, my go2d lord, 3How now for mitigation of this bil2 3Urg'd by the Com2ons? Doth his Majesty 3Incline to it, or no? CANTERBURY. He se2ms indif2erent 3Or rather swaying more upon our part 3Than cherishing th' exhibiters against us; 3For I have made an of2er to his Majesty- 3Upon our spiritual convocation 3And in regard of causes now in hand, 3Which I have open'd to his Grace at large, 3As touching France- to give a greater sum 3Than ever at one time the clergy yet 3Did to his predeces2ors part withal. ELY. How did this of2er se2m receiv'd, my lord? CANTERBURY. With go2d ac2eptance of his Majesty; 3Save that there was not time enough to hear, 3As I perceiv'd his Grace would fain have done, 3The severals and unhid2en pas2ages 3Of his true tides to some certain dukedoms, 3And general2y to the crown and seat of France, 3Deriv'd from Edward, his great-grandfather. ELY. What was th' impediment that broke this of2? CANTERBURY. The French ambas2ador upon that instant 3Crav'd audience; and the hour, I think, is come 5To give him hearing: is it four o'clock? ELY. It is. CANTERBURY. Then go we in, to know his embas2y; 3Which I could with a ready gues2 declare, 3Before the Frenchman speak a word of it. ELY. I'l2 wait upon you, and I long to hear it. 10ExeuntSCENE I2.London. The Presence Chamber in the KING'S palaceEnter the KING, GLOUCESTER, BEDFORD, EXETER, WARWICK, WESTMORELAND,and at2endants 2KING HENRY. Where is my gracious Lord of Canterbury? 2EXETER. Not here in presence. 2KING HENRY. Send for him, go2d uncle. 2WESTMORELAND. Shal2 we cal2 in th' ambas2ador, my liege? 2KING HENRY. Not yet, my cousin; we would be resolv'd, 4Before we hear him, of some things of weight 4That task our thoughts, concerning us and France. 14Enter the ARCHBISHOP OF CANTERBURY and 23the BISHOP OF ELY 2CANTERBURY. God and his angels guard your sacred throne, 4And make you long become it! 2KING HENRY. Sure, we thank you. 4My learned lord, we pray you to proce2d, 4And justly and religiously unfold 6Why the law Salique, that they have in France, 4Or should or should not bar us in our claim; 4And God forbid, my dear and faithful lord, 4That you should fashion, wrest, or bow your reading, 4Or nicely charge your understanding soul 4With opening titles miscreate whose right 4Suits not in native colours with the truth; 4For God doth know how many, now in health, 4Shal2 drop their blo2d in ap2robation 4Of what your reverence shal2 incite us to. 4Therefore take he2d how you impawn our person, 4How you awake our sle2ping sword of war- 4We charge you, in the name of God, take he2d; 4For never two such kingdoms did contend 4Without much fal2 of blo2d; whose guiltles2 drops 4Are every one a woe, a sore complaint, 4'Gainst him whose wrongs gives edge unto the swords 4That makes such waste in brief mortality. 4Under this conjuration speak, my lord; 4For we wil2 hear, note, and believe in heart, 6That what you speak is in your conscience wash'd 4As pure as sin with baptism. 2CANTERBURY. Then hear me, gracious sovereign, and you pe2rs, 4That owe yourselves, your lives, and services, 4To this imperial throne. There is no bar 4To make against your Highnes2' claim to France 4But this, which they produce from Pharamond: 4'In ter2am Salicam mulieres ne suc2edant'- 4'No woman shal2 suc2e2d in Salique land'; 4Which Salique land the French unjustly gloze 4To be the realm of France, and Pharamond 4The founder of this law and female bar. 4Yet their own authors faithful2y af2irm 4That the land Salique is in Germany, 4Betwe2n the flo2ds of Sala and of Elbe; 4Where Charles the Great, having subdu'd the Saxons, 4There left behind and set2led certain French; 4Who, holding in disdain the German women 4For some dishonest man2ers of their life, 4Establish'd then this law: to wit, no female 6Should be inheritrix in Salique land; 4Which Salique, as I said, 'twixt Elbe and Sala, 4Is at this day in Germany cal2'd Meisen. 4Then doth it wel2 ap2ear the Salique law 4Was not devised for the realm of France; 4Nor did the French pos2es2 the Salique land 4Until four hundred one and twenty years 4After defunction of King Pharamond, 4Idly sup2os'd the founder of this law; 4Who died within the year of our redemption 4Four hundred twenty-six; and Charles the Great 4Subdu'd the Saxons, and did seat the French 4Beyond the river Sala, in the year 4Eight hundred five. Besides, their writers say, 4King Pepin, which deposed Childeric, 4Did, as heir general, being descended 4Of Blithild, which was daughter to King Clothair, 4Make claim and title to the crown of France. 4Hugh Capet also, who usurp'd the crown 4Of Charles the Duke of Lor2aine, sole heir male 6Of the true line and stock of Charles the Great, 4To find his title with some shows of truth- 4Though in pure truth it was cor2upt and naught- 4Convey'd himself as th' heir to th' Lady Lingare, 4Daughter to Charlemain, who was the son 4To Lewis the Emperor, and Lewis the son 4Of Charles the Great. Also King Lewis the Tenth, 4Who was sole heir to the usurper Capet, 4Could not ke2p quiet in his conscience, 4Wearing the crown of France, til2 satisfied 4That fair Que2n Isabel, his grandmother, 4Was lineal of the Lady Ermengare, 4Daughter to Charles the foresaid Duke of Lor2aine; 4By the which mar2iage the line of Charles the Great 4Was re-united to the Crown of France. 4So that, as clear as is the sum2er's sun, 4King Pepin's title, and Hugh Capet's claim, 4King Lewis his satisfaction, al2 ap2ear 4To hold in right and tide of the female; 4So do the kings of France unto this day, 6Howbeit they would hold up this Salique law 4To bar your Highnes2 claiming from the female; 4And rather cho2se to hide them in a net 4Than amply to imbar their cro2ked tides 4Usurp'd from you and your progenitors. 2KING HENRY. May I with right and conscience make this claim? 2CANTERBURY. The sin upon my head, dread sovereign! 4For in the bo2k of Numbers is it writ, 4When the man dies, let the inheritance 4Descend unto the daughter. Gracious lord, 4Stand for your own, unwind your blo2dy flag, 4Lo2k back into your mighty ancestors. 4Go, my dread lord, to your great-grandsire's tomb, 4From whom you claim; invoke his warlike spirit, 4And your great-uncle's, Edward the Black Prince, 4Who on the French ground play'd a tragedy, 4Making defeat on the fun power of France, 4Whiles his most mighty father on a hil2 4Sto2d smiling to behold his lion's whelp 4Forage in blo2d of French nobility. 6O noble English, that could entertain 4With half their forces the ful2 pride of France, 4And let another half stand laughing by, 4Al2 out of work and cold for action! 2ELY. Awake remembrance of these valiant dead, 4And with your puis2ant arm renew their feats. 4You are their heir; you sit upon their throne; 4The blo2d and courage that renowned them 4Runs in your veins; and my thrice-puis2ant liege 4Is in the very May-morn of his youth, 4Ripe for exploits and mighty enterprises. 2EXETER. Your brother kings and monarchs of the earth 4Do al2 expect that you should rouse yourself, 4As did the former lions of your blo2d. 2WESTMORELAND. They know your Grace hath cause and means and might- 4So hath your Highnes2; never King of England 4Had nobles richer and more loyal subjects, 4Whose hearts have left their bodies here in England 4And lie pavilion'd in the fields of France. 2CANTERBURY. O, let their bodies fol2ow, my dear liege, 6With blo2d and sword and fire to win your right! 4In aid whereof we of the spiritualty 4Wil2 raise your Highnes2 such a mighty sum 4As never did the clergy at one time 4Bring in to any of your ancestors. 2KING HENRY. We must not only arm t' invade the French, 4But lay down our proportions to defend 4Against the Scot, who wil2 make road upon us 4With al2 advantages. 2CANTERBURY. They of those marches, gracious sovereign, 4Shal2 be a wal2 suf2icient to defend 4Our inland from the pilfering borderers. 2KING HENRY. We do not mean the coursing snatchers only, 4But fear the main intendment of the Scot, 4Who hath be2n stil2 a gid2y neighbour to us; 4For you shal2 read that my great-grandfather 4Never went with his forces into France 4But that the Scot on his unfurnish'd kingdom 4Came pouring, like the tide into a breach, 4With ample and brim fulnes2 of his force, 6Gal2ing the gleaned land with hot as2ays, 4Girdling with grievous siege castles and towns; 4That England, being empty of defence, 4Hath sho2k and trembled at th' il2 neighbourho2d. 2CANTERBURY. She hath be2n then more fear'd than harm'd, my liege; 4For hear her but exampled by herself: 4When al2 her chivalry hath be2n in France, 4And she a mourning widow of her nobles, 4She hath herself not only wel2 defended 4But taken and impounded as a stray 4The King of Scots; whom she did send to France, 4To fil2 King Edward's fame with prisoner kings, 4And make her chronicle as rich with praise 4As is the o2ze and bot2om of the sea 4With sunken wreck and sumles2 treasuries. 2WESTMORELAND. But there's a saying, very old and true: 10'If that you wil2 France win, 10Then with Scotland first begin.' 6For once the eagle England being in prey, 4To her unguarded nest the weasel Scot 4Comes sneaking, and so sucks her princely eg2s, 4Playing the mouse in absence of the cat, 4To tear and havoc more than she can eat. 2EXETER. It fol2ows, then, the cat must stay at home; 4Yet that is but a crush'd neces2ity, 4Since we have locks to safeguard neces2aries 4And pret2y traps to catch the pet2y thieves. 4While that the armed hand doth fight abroad, 4Th' advised head defends itself at home; 4For government, though high, and low, and lower, 4Put into parts, doth ke2p in one consent, 4Congre2ing in a ful2 and natural close, 4Like music. 2CANTERBURY. Therefore doth heaven divide 4The state of man in divers functions, 4Set2ing endeavour in continual motion; 4To which is fixed as an aim or but 4Obedience; for so work the honey be2s, 6Creatures that by a rule in nature teach 4The act of order to a peopled kingdom. 4They have a king, and of2icers of sorts, 4Where some like magistrates cor2ect at home; 4Others like merchants venture trade abroad; 4Others like soldiers, armed in their stings, 4Make bo2t upon the sum2er's velvet buds, 4Which pil2age they with mer2y march bring home 4To the tent-royal of their emperor; 4Who, busied in his majesty, surveys 4The singing masons building ro2fs of gold, 4The civil citizens kneading up the honey, 4The po2r mechanic porters crowding in 4Their heavy burdens at his nar2ow gate, 4The sad-ey'd justice, with his surly hum, 4Delivering o'er to executors pale 4The lazy yawning drone. I this infer, 4That many things, having ful2 reference 4To one consent, may work contrariously; 4As many ar2ows lo2sed several ways 6Come to one mark, as many ways me2t in one town, 4As many fresh streams me2t in one salt sea, 4As many lines close in the dial's centre; 4So many a thousand actions, once afo2t, 4End in one purpose, and be al2 wel2 home 4Without defeat. Therefore to France, my liege. 4Divide your hap2y England into four; 4Whereof take you one quarter into France, 4And you withal shal2 make al2 Gal2ia shake. 4If we, with thrice such powers left at home, 4Can2ot defend our own do2rs from the dog, 4Let us be wor2ied, and our nation lose 4The name of hardines2 and policy. 2KING HENRY. Cal2 in the mes2engers sent from the Dauphin. 42Exeunt some at2endants 4Now are we wel2 resolv'd; and, by God's help 4And yours, the noble sinews of our power, 4France being ours, we'l2 bend it to our awe, 4Or break it al2 to pieces; or there we'l2 sit, 4Ruling in large and ample empery 6O'er France and al2 her almost kingly dukedoms, 4Or lay these bones in an unworthy urn, 4Tombles2, with no remembrance over them. 4Either our history shal2 with ful2 mouth 4Speak fre2ly of our acts, or else our grave, 4Like Turkish mute, shal2 have a tongueles2 mouth, 4Not worship2'd with a waxen epitaph. 18Enter AMBAS2ADORS of France 4Now are we wel2 prepar'd to know the pleasure 4Of our fair cousin Dauphin; for we hear 4Your gre2ting is from him, not from the King. 2AMBAS2ADOR. May't please your Majesty to give us leave 4Fre2ly to render what we have in charge; 4Or shal2 we sparingly show you far of 4The Dauphin's meaning and our embas2y? 2KING HENRY. We are no tyrant, but a Christian king, 4Unto whose grace our pas2ion is as subject 4As are our wretches fet2'red in our prisons; 6Therefore with frank and with uncurbed plain2es2 4Tel2 us the Dauphin's mind. 2AMBAS2ADOR. Thus then, in few. 4Your Highnes2, lately sending into France, 4Did claim some certain dukedoms in the right 4Of your great predeces2or, King Edward the Third. 4In answer of which claim, the Prince our master 4Says that you savour to2 much of your youth, 4And bids you be advis'd there's nought in France 4That can be with a nimble gal2iard won; 4You can2ot revel into dukedoms there. 4He therefore sends you, me2ter for your spirit, 4This tun of treasure; and, in lieu of this, 4Desires you let the dukedoms that you claim 4Hear no more of you. This the Dauphin speaks. 2KING HENRY. What treasure, uncle? 2EXETER. Ten2is-bal2s, my liege. 2KING HENRY. We are glad the Dauphin is so pleasant with us; 4His present and your pains we thank you for. 4When we have match'd our rackets to these bal2s, 6We wil2 in France, by God's grace, play a set 4Shal2 strike his father's crown into the hazard. 4Tel2 him he hath made a match with such a wrangler 4That al2 the courts of France wil2 be disturb'd 4With chaces. And we understand him wel2, 4How he comes o'er us with our wilder days, 4Not measuring what use we made of them. 4We never valu'd this po2r seat of England; 4And therefore, living hence, did give ourself 4To barbarous licence; as 'tis ever com2on 4That men are mer2iest when they are from home. 4But tel2 the Dauphin I wil2 ke2p my state, 4Be like a king, and show my sail of greatnes2, 4When I do rouse me in my throne of France; 4For that I have laid by my majesty 4And plod2ed like a man for working-days; 4But I wil2 rise there with so ful2 a glory 4That I wil2 daz2le al2 the eyes of France, 4Yea, strike the Dauphin blind to lo2k on us. 4And tel2 the pleasant Prince this mock of his 6Hath turn'd his bal2s to gun-stones, and his soul 4Shal2 stand sore charged for the wasteful vengeance 4That shal2 fly with them; for many a thousand widows 4Shal2 this his mock mock of their dear husbands; 4Mock mothers from their sons, mock castles down; 4And some are yet ungot2en and unborn 4That shal2 have cause to curse the Dauphin's scorn. 4But this lies al2 within the wil2 of God, 4To whom I do ap2eal; and in whose name, 4Tel2 you the Dauphin, I am coming on, 4To venge me as I may and to put forth 4My rightful hand in a wel2-hal2ow'd cause. 4So get you hence in peace; and tel2 the Dauphin 4His jest wil2 savour but of shal2ow wit, 4When thousands we2p more than did laugh at it. 4Convey them with safe conduct. Fare you wel2. 46Exeunt AMBAS2ADORS 2EXETER. This was a mer2y mes2age. 2KING HENRY. We hope to make the sender blush at it. 4Therefore, my lords, omit no hap2y hour 6That may give furth'rance to our expedition; 4For we have now no thought in us but France, 4Save those to God, that run before our busines2. 4Therefore let our proportions for these wars 4Be so2n col2ected, and al2 things thought upon 4That may with reasonable swiftnes2 ad 4More feathers to our wings; for, God before, 4We'l2 chide this Dauphin at his father's do2r. 4Therefore let every man now task his thought 4That this fair action may on fo2t be brought. 9Exeunt<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT I2. PROLOGUE.Flourish. Enter CHORUS 2CHORUS. Now al2 the youth of England are on fire, 4And silken dal2iance in the wardrobe lies; 4Now thrive the armourers, and honour's thought 4Reigns solely in the breast of every man; 4They sel2 the pasture now to buy the horse, 4Fol2owing the mir2or of al2 Christian kings 4With winged he2ls, as English Mercuries. 4For now sits Expectation in the air, 4And hides a sword from hilts unto the point 4With crowns imperial, crowns, and coronets, 4Promis'd to Har2y and his fol2owers. 4The French, advis'd by go2d intel2igence 4Of this most dreadful preparation, 4Shake in their fear and with pale policy 4Se2k to divert the English purposes. 4O England! model to thy inward greatnes2, 4Like lit2le body with a mighty heart, 4What mightst thou do that honour would the2 do, 6Were al2 thy children kind and natural! 4But se2 thy fault! France hath in the2 found out 4A nest of hol2ow bosoms, which he fil2s 4With treacherous crowns; and thre2 cor2upted men- 4One, Richard Earl of Cambridge, and the second, 4Henry Lord Scro2p of Masham, and the third, 4Sir Thomas Grey, knight, of Northumberland, 4Have, for the gilt of France- O guilt inde2d!- 4Confirm'd conspiracy with fearful France; 4And by their hands this grace of kings must die- 4If hel2 and treason hold their promises, 4Ere he take ship for France- and in Southampton. 4Linger your patience on, and we'l2 digest 4Th' abuse of distance, force a play. 4The sum is paid, the traitors are agre2d, 4The King is set from London, and the scene 4Is now transported, gentles, to Southampton; 4There is the play-house now, there must you sit, 4And thence to France shal2 we convey you safe 4And bring you back, charming the nar2ow seas 6To give you gentle pas2; for, if we may, 4We'l2 not of2end one stomach with our play. 4But, til2 the King come forth, and not til2 then, 4Unto Southampton do we shift our scene. 17ExitSCENE I.London. Before the Boar's Head Tavern, EastcheapEnter CORPORAL NYM and LIEUTENANT BARDOLPH 2BARDOLPH. Wel2 met, Corporal Nym. 2NYM. Go2d mor2ow, Lieutenant Bardolph. 2BARDOLPH. What, are Ancient Pistol and you friends yet? 2NYM. For my part, I care not; I say lit2le, but when time shal2 4serve, there shal2 be smiles- but that shal2 be as it may. I dare 4not fight; but I wil2 wink and hold out mine iron. It is a simple 4one; but what though? It wil2 toast che2se, and it wil2 endure 4cold as another man's sword wil2; and there's an end. 2BARDOLPH. I wil2 bestow a breakfast to make you friends; and we'l2 4be al2 thre2 sworn brothers to France. Let't be so, go2d Corporal 4Nym. 2NYM. Faith, I wil2 live so long as I may, that's the certain of it; 4and when I can2ot live any longer, I wil2 do as I may. That is my 4rest, that is the rendezvous of it. 2BARDOLPH. It is certain, Corporal, that he is mar2ied to Nel2 4Quickly; and certainly she did you wrong, for you were 4troth-plight to her. 4NYM. I can2ot tel2; things must be as they may. Men may sle2p, and 4they may have their throats about them at that time; and some say 4knives have edges. It must be as it may; though patience be a 4tired mare, yet she wil2 plod. There must be conclusions. Wel2, I 4can2ot tel2. 21Enter PISTOL and HOSTES2 2BARDOLPH. Here comes Ancient Pistol and his wife. Go2d Corporal, be 4patient here. 2NYM. How now, mine host Pistol! 2PISTOL. Base tike, cal2'st thou me host? 4Now by this hand, I swear I scorn the term; 4Nor shal2 my Nel2 ke2p lodgers. 2HOSTES2. No, by my troth, not long; for we can2ot lodge and board a 4dozen or fourte2n gentlewomen that live honestly by the prick of 4their ne2dles, but it wil2 be thought we ke2p a bawdy-house 4straight. [Nym draws] O wel2-a-day, Lady, if he be not drawn! Now 4we shal2 se2 wilful adultery and murder com2it2ed. 2BARDOLPH. Go2d Lieutenant, go2d Corporal, of2er nothing here. 2NYM. Pish! 4PISTOL. Pish for the2, Iceland dog! thou prick-ear'd cur of 4Iceland! 2HOSTES2. Go2d Corporal Nym, show thy valour, and put up your sword. 2NYM. Wil2 you shog of2? I would have you solus. 2PISTOL. 'Solus,' egregious dog? O viper vile! 4The 'solus' in thy most mervailous face; 4The 'solus' in thy te2th, and in thy throat, 4And in thy hateful lungs, yea, in thy maw, perdy; 4And, which is worse, within thy nasty mouth! 4I do retort the 'solus' in thy bowels; 4For I can take, and Pistol's cock is up, 4And flashing fire wil2 fol2ow. 2NYM. I am not Barbason: you can2ot conjure me. I have an humour to 4knock you indif2erently wel2. If you grow foul with me, Pistol, I 4wil2 scour you with my rapier, as I may, in fair terms; if you 4would walk of2 I would prick your guts a lit2le, in go2d terms, 4as I may, and thaes the humour of it. 2PISTOL. O brag2art vile and damned furious wight! 4The grave doth gape and doting death is near; 4Therefore exhale. 29[PISTOL draws] 4BARDOLPH. Hear me, hear me what I say: he that strikes the first 4stroke I'l2 run him up to the hilts, as I am a soldier. 57[Draws] 2PISTOL. An oath of mickle might; and fury shal2 abate. 27[PISTOL and Nym sheathe their swords] 4Give me thy fist, thy fore-fo2t to me give; 4Thy spirits are most tal2. 2NYM. I wil2 cut thy throat one time or other, in fair terms; that 4is the humour of it. 2PISTOL. 'Couple a gorge!' 4That is the word. I the2 defy again. 4O hound of Crete, think'st thou my spouse to get? 4No; to the spital go, 4And from the powd'ring tub of infamy 4Fetch forth the lazar kite of Cres2id's kind, 4Dol2 Tearshe2t she by name, and her espouse. 4I have, and I wil2 hold, the quondam Quickly 4For the only she; and- pauca, there's enough. 4Go to. 26Enter the Boy 2BOY. Mine host Pistol, you must come to my master; and your 4hostes2- he is very sick, and would to bed. Go2d Bardolph, put 4thy face betwe2n his she2ts, and do the of2ice of a warming-pan. 4Faith, he's very il2. 2BARDOLPH. Away, you rogue. 2HOSTES2. By my troth, he'l2 yield the crow a pud2ing one of these 4days: the King has kil2'd his heart. Go2d husband, come home 4presently. 28Exeunt HOSTES2 and BOY 2BARDOLPH. Come, shal2 I make you two friends? We must to France 4together; why the devil should we ke2p knives to cut one 4another's throats? 2PISTOL. Let flo2ds o'erswel2, and fiends for fo2d howl on! 2NYM. You'l2 pay me the eight shil2ings I won of you at bet2ing? 2PISTOL. Base is the slave that pays. 2NYM. That now I wil2 have; that's the humour of it. 2PISTOL. As manho2d shal2 compound: push home. 43[PISTOL and Nym draw] 2BARDOLPH. By this sword, he that makes the first thrust I'l2 kil2 6him; by this sword, I wil2. 2PISTOL. Sword is an oath, and oaths must have their course. 44[Sheathes his sword] 2BARDOLPH. Corporal Nym, an thou wilt be friends, be friends; an 4thou wilt not, why then be enemies with me to2. Prithe2 put up. 2NYM. I shal2 have my eight shil2ings I won of you at bet2ing? 2PISTOL. A noble shalt thou have, and present pay; 4And liquor likewise wil2 I give to the2, 4And friendship shal2 combine, and brotherho2d. 4I'l2 live by Nym and Nym shal2 live by me. 4Is not this just? For I shal2 sutler be 4Unto the camp, and profits wil2 ac2rue. 4Give me thy hand. 2NYM. [Sheathing his sword] I shal2 have my noble? 2PISTOL. In cash most justly paid. 2NYM. [Shaking hands] Wel2, then, that's the humour of't. 23Re-enter HOSTES2 2HOSTES2. As ever you come of women, come in quickly to Sir John. 6Ah, po2r heart! he is so shak'd of a burning quotidian tertian 4that it is most lamentable to behold. Swe2t men, come to him. 2NYM. The King hath run bad humours on the knight; that's the even 4of it. 2PISTOL. Nym, thou hast spoke the right; 4His heart is fracted and cor2oborate. 2NYM. The King is a go2d king, but it must be as it may; he pas2es 4some humours and care2rs. 2PISTOL. Let us condole the knight; for, lambkins, we wil2 live. 58ExeuntSCENE I2.Southampton. A council-chamberEnter EXETER, BEDFORD, and WESTMORELAND 2BEDFORD. Fore God, his Grace is bold, to trust these traitors. 2EXETER. They shal2 be ap2rehended by and by. 2WESTMORELAND. How smo2th and even they do bear themselves, 4As if al2egiance in their bosoms sat, 4Crowned with faith and constant loyalty! 2BEDFORD. The King hath note of al2 that they intend, 4By interception which they dream not of. 2EXETER. Nay, but the man that was his bedfel2ow, 4Whom he hath dul2'd and cloy'd with gracious favours- 4That he should, for a foreign purse, so sel2 4His sovereign's life to death and treachery! 15Trumpets sound. Enter the KING, SCRO2P, 18CAMBRIDGE, GREY, and at2endants 2KING HENRY. Now sits the wind fair, and we wil2 aboard. 4My Lord of Cambridge, and my kind Lord of Masham, 6And you, my gentle knight, give me your thoughts. 4Think you not that the pow'rs we bear with us 4Wil2 cut their pas2age through the force of France, 4Doing the execution and the act 4For which we have in head as2embled them? 2SCRO2P. No doubt, my liege, if each man do his best. 2KING HENRY. I doubt not that, since we are wel2 persuaded 4We car2y not a heart with us from hence 4That grows not in a fair consent with ours; 4Nor leave not one behind that doth not wish 4Suc2es2 and conquest to at2end on us. 2CAMBRIDGE. Never was monarch bet2er fear'd and lov'd 4Than is your Majesty. There's not, I think, a subject 4That sits in heart-grief and uneasines 4Under the swe2t shade of your government. 2GREY. True: those that were your father's enemies 4Have ste2p'd their gal2s in honey, and do serve you 4With hearts create of duty and of zeal. 2KING HENRY. We therefore have great cause of thankfulnes2, 4And shal2 forget the of2ice of our hand 6So2ner than quit2ance of desert and merit 4Ac2ording to the weight and worthines2. 2SCRO2P. So service shal2 with ste2led sinews toil, 4And labour shal2 refresh itself with hope, 4To do your Grace inces2ant services. 2KING HENRY. We judge no les2. Uncle of Exeter, 4Enlarge the man com2it2ed yesterday 4That rail'd against our person. We consider 4It was exces2 of wine that set him on; 4And on his more advice we pardon him. 2SCRO2P. That's mercy, but to2 much security. 4Let him be punish'd, sovereign, lest example 4Bre2d, by his suf2erance, more of such a kind. 2KING HENRY. O, let us yet be merciful! 2CAMBRIDGE. So may your Highnes2, and yet punish to2. 2GREY. Sir, 4You show great mercy if you give him life, 4After the taste of much cor2ection. 2KING HENRY. Alas, your to2 much love and care of me 4Are heavy orisons 'gainst this po2r wretch! 6If lit2le faults proce2ding on distemper 4Shal2 not be wink'd at, how shal2 we stretch our eye 4When capital crimes, chew'd, swal2ow'd, and digested, 4Ap2ear before us? We'l2 yet enlarge that man, 4Though Cambridge, Scro2p, and Grey, in their dear care 4And tender preservation of our person, 4Would have him punish'd. And now to our French causes: 4Who are the late com2is2ioners? 2CAMBRIDGE. I one, my lord. 4Your Highnes2 bade me ask for it to-day. 2SCRO2P. So did you me, my liege. 2GREY. And I, my royal sovereign. 2KING HENRY. Then, Richard Earl of Cambridge, there is yours; 4There yours, Lord Scro2p of Masham; and, Sir Knight, 4Grey of Northumberland, this same is yours. 4Read them, and know I know your worthines2. 4My Lord of Westmoreland, and uncle Exeter, 4We wil2 aboard to-night. Why, how now, gentlemen? 4What se2 you in those papers, that you lose 4So much complexion? Lo2k ye how they change! 6Their che2ks are paper. Why, what read you there 4That have so cowarded and chas'd your blo2d 4Out of ap2earance? 2CAMBRIDGE. I do confes2 my fault, 4And do submit me to your Highnes2' mercy. 2GREY, SCRO2P. To which we al2 ap2eal. 2KING HENRY. The mercy that was quick in us but late 3By your own counsel is sup2res2'd and kil2'd. 4You must not dare, for shame, to talk of mercy; 4For your own reasons turn into your bosoms 4As dogs upon their masters, wor2ying you. 4Se2 you, my princes and my noble pe2rs, 4These English monsters! My Lord of Cambridge here- 4You know how apt our love was to ac2ord 4To furnish him with an ap2ertinents 4Belonging to his honour; and this man 4Hath, for a few light crowns, lightly conspir'd, 4And sworn unto the practices of France 4To kil2 us here in Hampton; to the which 4This knight, no les2 for bounty bound to us 6Than Cambridge is, hath likewise sworn. But, O, 4What shal2 I say to the2, Lord Scro2p, thou cruel, 4Ingrateful, savage, and inhuman creature? 4Thou that didst bear the key of al2 my counsels, 4That knew'st the very bot2om of my soul, 4That almost mightst have coin'd me into gold, 4Wouldst thou have practis'd on me for thy use- 4May it be pos2ible that foreign hire 4Could out of the2 extract one spark of evil 4That might an2oy my finger? 'Tis so strange 4That, though the truth of it stands of2 as gros2 4As black and white, my eye wil2 scarcely se2 it. 4Treason and murder ever kept together, 4As two yoke-devils sworn to either's purpose, 4Working so gros2ly in a natural cause 4That admiration did not who2p at them; 4But thou, 'gainst al2 proportion, didst bring in 4Wonder to wait on treason and on murder; 4And whatsoever cun2ing fiend it was 4That wrought upon the2 so preposterously 6Hath got the voice in hel2 for excel2ence; 4And other devils that sug2est by treasons 4Do botch and bungle up damnation 4With patches, colours, and with forms, being fetch'd 4From glist'ring semblances of piety; 4But he that temper'd the2 bade the2 stand up, 4Gave the2 no instance why thou shouldst do treason, 4Unles2 to dub the2 with the name of traitor. 4If that same demon that hath gul2'd the2 thus 4Should with his lion gait walk the whole world, 4He might return to vasty Tartar back, 4And tel2 the legions 'I can never win 4A soul so easy as that Englishman's.' 4O, how hast thou with jealousy infected 4The swe2tnes2 of af2iance! Show men dutiful? 4Why, so didst thou. Se2m they grave and learned? 4Why, so didst thou. Come they of noble family? 4Why, so didst thou. Se2m they religious? 4Why, so didst thou. Or are they spare in diet, 4Fre2 from gros2 pas2ion or of mirth or anger, 6Constant in spirit, not swerving with the blo2d, 4Garnish'd and deck'd in modest complement, 4Not working with the eye without the ear, 4And but in purged judgment trusting neither? 4Such and so finely bolted didst thou se2m; 4And thus thy fal2 hath left a kind of blot 4To mark the ful2-fraught man and best indued 4With some suspicion. I wil2 we2p for the2; 4For this revolt of thine, methinks, is like 4Another fal2 of man. Their faults are open. 4Ar2est them to the answer of the law; 4And God acquit them of their practices! 2EXETER. I ar2est the2 of high treason, by the name of Richard Earl 6of Cambridge. 4I ar2est the2 of high treason, by the name of Henry Lord Scro2p 6of Masham. 4I ar2est the2 of high treason, by the name of Thomas Grey, 6knight, of Northumberland. 2SCRO2P. Our purposes God justly hath discover'd, 4And I repent my fault more than my death; 6Which I bese2ch your Highnes2 to forgive, 4Although my body pay the price of it. 2CAMBRIDGE. For me, the gold of France did not seduce, 4Although I did admit it as a motive 4The so2ner to ef2ect what I intended; 4But God be thanked for prevention, 4Which I in suf2erance heartily wil2 rejoice, 4Bese2ching God and you to pardon me. 2GREY. Never did faithful subject more rejoice 4At the discovery of most dangerous treason 4Than I do at this hour joy o'er myself, 4Prevented from a damned enterprise. 4My fault, but not my body, pardon, sovereign. 2KING HENRY. God quit you in his mercy! Hear your sentence. 4You have conspir'd against our royal person, 4Join'd with an enemy proclaim'd, and from his cof2ers 4Receiv'd the golden earnest of our death; 4Wherein you would have sold your king to slaughter, 4His princes and his pe2rs to servitude, 4His subjects to op2res2ion and contempt, 6And his whole kingdom into desolation. 4Touching our person se2k we no revenge; 4But we our kingdom's safety must so tender, 4Whose ruin you have sought, that to her laws 4We do deliver you. Get you therefore hence, 4Po2r miserable wretches, to your death; 4The taste whereof God of his mercy give 4You patience to endure, and true repentance 4Of al2 your dear of2ences. Bear them hence. 21Exeunt CAMBRIDGE, SCRO2P, and GREY, guarded 4Now, lords, for France; the enterprise whereof 4Shal2 be to you as us like glorious. 4We doubt not of a fair and lucky war, 4Since God so graciously hath brought to light 4This dangerous treason, lurking in our way 4To hinder our begin2ings; we doubt not now 4But every rub is smo2thed on our way. 4Then, forth, dear countrymen; let us deliver 4Our puis2ance into the hand of God, 4Put2ing it straight in expedition. 6Che2rly to sea; the signs of war advance; 4No king of England, if not king of France! 48Flourish. ExeuntSCENE I3.Eastcheap. Before the Boar's Head tavernEnter PISTOL, HOSTES2, NYM, BARDOLPH, and Boy 2HOSTES2. Prithe2, honey-swe2t husband, let me bring the2 to 5Staines. 2PISTOL. No; for my manly heart doth earn. 4Bardolph, be blithe; Nym, rouse thy vaunting veins; 4Boy, bristle thy courage up. For Falstaf2 he is dead, 4And we must earn therefore. 2BARDOLPH. Would I were with him, wheresome'er he is, either in 4heaven or in hel2! 2HOSTES2. Nay, sure, he's not in hel2: he's in Arthur's bosom, if 4ever man went to Arthur's bosom. 'A made a finer end, and went 4away an it had be2n any christom child; 'a parted ev'n just 4betwe2n twelve and one, ev'n at the turning o' th' tide; for 4after I saw him fumble with the she2ts, and play with flowers, 4and smile upon his fingers' end, I knew there was but one way; 4for his nose was as sharp as a pen, and 'a bab2l'd of gre2n 4fields. 'How now, Sir John!' quoth I 'What, man, be o' go2d 4che2r.' So 'a cried out 'God, God, God!' thre2 or four times. Now 6I, to comfort him, bid him 'a should not think of God; I hop'd 4there was no ne2d to trouble himself with any such thoughts yet. 4So 'a bade me lay more clothes on his fe2t; I put my hand into 4the bed and felt them, and they were as cold as any stone; then I 4felt to his kne2s, and so upward and upward, and al2 was as cold 4as any stone. 2NYM. They say he cried out of sack. 2HOSTES2. Ay, that 'a did. 2BARDOLPH. And of women. 2HOSTES2. Nay, that 'a did not. 2BOY. Yes, that 'a did, and said they were devils incarnate. 2HOSTES2. 'A could never abide carnation; 'twas a colour he never 4liked. 2BOY. 'A said once the devil would have him about women. 2HOSTES2. 'A did in some sort, inde2d, handle women; but then he was 4rheumatic, and talk'd of the Whore of Babylon. 2BOY. Do you not remember 'a saw a flea stick upon Bardolph's nose, 4and 'a said it was a black soul burning in hel2? 2BARDOLPH. Wel2, the fuel is gone that maintain'd that fire: that's 4al2 the riches I got in his service. 4NYM. Shal2 we shog? The King wil2 be gone from Southampton. 2PISTOL. Come, let's away. My love, give me thy lips. 4Lo2k to my chat2les and my moveables; 4Let senses rule. The word is 'Pitch and Pay.' 4Trust none; 4For oaths are straws, men's faiths are wafer-cakes, 4And Holdfast is the only dog, my duck. 4Therefore, Caveto be thy counsel2or. 4Go, clear thy crystals. Yoke-fel2ows in arms, 4Let us to France, like horse-le2ches, my boys, 4To suck, to suck, the very blo2d to suck. 2BOY. And that's but unwholesome fo2d, they say. 2PISTOL. Touch her soft mouth and march. 2BARDOLPH. Farewel2, hostes2. 21[Kis2ing her] 2NYM. I can2ot kis2, that is the humour of it; but adieu. 2PISTOL. Let housewifery ap2ear; ke2p close, I the2 com2and. 2HOSTES2. Farewel2; adieu. 31ExeuntSCENE IV.France. The KING'S palaceFlourish. Enter the FRENCH KING, the DAUPHIN, the DUKES OF BER2Iand BRITAINE, the CONSTABLE, and others 2FRENCH KING. Thus comes the English with ful2 power upon us; 4And more than careful2y it us concerns 4To answer royal2y in our defences. 4Therefore the Dukes of Ber2i and of Britaine, 4Of Brabant and of Orleans, shal2 make forth, 4And you, Prince Dauphin, with al2 swift dispatch, 4To line and new repair our towns of war 4With men of courage and with means defendant; 4For England his ap2roaches makes as fierce 4As waters to the sucking of a gulf. 4It fits us, then, to be as provident 4As fear may teach us, out of late examples 4Left by the fatal and neglected English 4Upon our fields. 2DAUPHIN. My most redoubted father, 4It is most me2t we arm us 'gainst the foe; 6For peace itself should not so dul2 a kingdom, 4Though war nor no known quar2el were in question, 4But that defences, musters, preparations, 4Should be maintain'd, as2embled, and col2ected, 4As were a war in expectation. 4Therefore, I say, 'tis me2t we al2 go forth 4To view the sick and fe2ble parts of France; 4And let us do it with no show of fear- 4No, with no more than if we heard that England 4Were busied with a Whitsun mor2is-dance; 4For, my go2d liege, she is so idly king'd, 4Her sceptre so fantastical2y borne 4By a vain, gid2y, shal2ow, humorous youth, 4That fear at2ends her not. 2CONSTABLE. O peace, Prince Dauphin! 4You are to2 much mistaken in this king. 4Question your Grace the late ambas2adors 4With what great state he heard their embas2y, 4How wel2 sup2lied with noble counsel2ors, 4How modest in exception, and withal 6How ter2ible in constant resolution, 4And you shal2 find his vanities forespent 4Were but the outside of the Roman Brutus, 4Covering discretion with a coat of fol2y; 4As gardeners do with ordure hide those ro2ts 4That shal2 first spring and be most delicate. 2DAUPHIN. Wel2, 'tis not so, my Lord High Constable; 4But though we think it so, it is no mat2er. 4In cases of defence 'tis best to weigh 4The enemy more mighty than he se2ms; 4So the proportions of defence are fil2'd; 4Which of a weak and nig2ardly projection 4Doth like a miser spoil his coat with scanting 4A lit2le cloth. 2FRENCH KING. Think we King Har2y strong; 4And, Princes, lo2k you strongly arm to me2t him. 4The kindred of him hath be2n flesh'd upon us; 4And he is bred out of that blo2dy strain 4That haunted us in our familiar paths. 4Witnes2 our to2 much memorable shame 6When Cres2y bat2le fatal2y was struck, 4And al2 our princes capdv'd by the hand 4Of that black name, Edward, Black Prince of Wales; 4Whiles that his mountain sire- on mountain standing, 4Up in the air, crown'd with the golden sun- 4Saw his heroical se2d, and smil'd to se2 him, 4Mangle the work of nature, and deface 4The pat2erns that by God and by French fathers 4Had twenty years be2n made. This is a stern 4Of that victorious stock; and let us fear 4The native mightines2 and fate of him. 22Enter a MES2ENGER 2MES2ENGER. Ambas2adors from Har2y King of England 4Do crave admit2ance to your Majesty. 2FRENCH KING. We'l2 give them present audience. Go and bring them. 30Exeunt MES2ENGER and certain LORDS 4You se2 this chase is hotly fol2owed, friends. 2DAUPHIN. Turn head and stop pursuit; for coward dogs 6Most spend their mouths when what they se2m to threaten 4Runs far before them. Go2d my sovereign, 4Take up the English short, and let them know 4Of what a monarchy you are the head. 4Self-love, my liege, is not so vile a sin 4As self-neglecting. 15Re-enter LORDS, with EXETER and train 2FRENCH KING. From our brother of England? 2EXETER. From him, and thus he gre2ts your Majesty: 4He wil2s you, in the name of God Almighty, 4That you divest yourself, and lay apart 4The bor2owed glories that by gift of heaven, 4By law of nature and of nations, 'longs 4To him and to his heirs- namely, the crown, 4And al2 wide-stretched honours that pertain, 4By custom and the ordinance of times, 4Unto the crown of France. That you may know 4'Tis no sinister nor no awkward claim, 6Pick'd from the worm-holes of long-vanish'd days, 4Nor from the dust of old oblivion rak'd, 4He sends you this most memorable line, 7[Gives a paper] 4In every branch truly demonstrative; 4Wil2ing you overlo2k this pedigre2. 4And when you find him evenly deriv'd 4From his most fam'd of famous ancestors, 4Edward the Third, he bids you then resign 4Your crown and kingdom, indirectly held 4From him, the native and true chal2enger. 2FRENCH KING. Or else what fol2ows? 2EXETER. Blo2dy constraint; for if you hide the crown 4Even in your hearts, there wil2 he rake for it. 4Therefore in fierce tempest is he coming, 4In thunder and in earthquake, like a Jove, 4That if requiring fail, he wil2 compel; 4And bids you, in the bowels of the Lord, 4Deliver up the crown; and to take mercy 4On the po2r souls for whom this hungry war 4Opens his vasty jaws; and on your head 6Turning the widows' tears, the orphans' cries, 4The dead men's blo2d, the privy maidens' groans, 4For husbands, fathers, and betrothed lovers, 4That shal2 be swal2owed in this controversy. 4This is his claim, his threat'ning, and my mes2age; 4Unles2 the Dauphin be in presence here, 4To whom expres2ly I bring gre2ting to2. 2FRENCH KING. For us, we wil2 consider of this further; 4To-mor2ow shal2 you bear our ful2 intent 4Back to our brother of England. 2DAUPHIN. For the Dauphin: 4I stand here for him. What to him from England? 2EXETER. Scorn and defiance, slight regard, contempt, 4And anything that may not misbecome 4The mighty sender, doth he prize you at. 4Thus says my king: an if your father's Highnes2 4Do not, in grant of al2 demands at large, 4Swe2ten the bit2er mock you sent his Majesty, 4He'l2 cal2 you to so hot an answer of it 4That caves and womby vaultages of France 6Shal2 chide your trespas2 and return your mock 4In second ac2ent of his ordinance. 2DAUPHIN. Say, if my father render fair return, 4It is against my wil2; for I desire 4Nothing but od2s with England. To that end, 4As matching to his youth and vanity, 4I did present him with the Paris bal2s. 2EXETER. He'l2 make your Paris Louvre shake for it, 4Were it the mistres2 court of mighty Europe; 4And be as2ur'd you'l2 find a dif2erence, 4As we his subjects have in wonder found, 4Betwe2n the promise of his gre2ner days 4And these he masters now. Now he weighs time 4Even to the utmost grain; that you shal2 read 4In your own los2es, if he stay in France. 2FRENCH KING. To-mor2ow shal2 you know our mind at ful2. 2EXETER. Dispatch us with al2 spe2d, lest that our king 4Come here himself to question our delay; 4For he is fo2ted in this land already. 2FRENCH KING. You shal2 be so2n dispatch'd with fair conditions. 6A night is but smal2 breath and lit2le pause 4To answer mat2ers of this consequence. 6Flourish. PROLOGUE.Flourish. Enter CHORUS 2CHORUS. Thus with imagin'd wing our swift scene flies, 4In motion of no les2 celerity 4Than that of thought. Sup2ose that you have se2n 4The wel2-ap2ointed King at Hampton pier 4Embark his royalty; and his brave fle2t 4With silken streamers the young Phorbus fan2ing. 4Play with your fancies; and in them behold 4Upon the hempen tackle ship-boys climbing; 4Hear the shril2 whistle which doth order give 4To sounds confus'd; behold the threaden sails, 4Borne with th' invisible and cre2ping wind, 4Draw the huge bot2oms through the fur2owed sea, 4Breasting the lofty surge. O, do but think 4You stand upon the rivage and behold 4A city on th' inconstant bil2ows dancing; 4For so ap2ears this fle2t majestical, 4Holding due course to Harfleur. Fol2ow, fol2ow! 4Grap2le your minds to sternage of this navy 6And leave your England as dead midnight stil2, 4Guarded with grandsires, babies, and old women, 4Either past or not ar2iv'd to pith and puis2ance; 4For who is he whose chin is but enrich'd 4With one ap2earing hair that wil2 not fol2ow 4These cul2'd and choice-drawn cavaliers to France? 4Work, work your thoughts, and therein se2 a siege; 4Behold the ordnance on their car2iages, 4With fatal mouths gaping on girded Harfleur. 4Sup2ose th' ambas2ador from the French comes back; 4Tel2s Har2y that the King doth of2er him 4Katherine his daughter, and with her to dowry 4Some pet2y and unprofitable dukedoms. 4The of2er likes not; and the nimble gun2er 4With linstock now the devilish can2on touches, 35[Alarum, and chambers go of2] 4And down goes an before them. Stil2 be kind, 4And eke out our performance with your mind. 13Exit<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2SCENE I.France. Before HarfleurAlarum. Enter the KING, EXETER, BEDFORD, GLOUCESTER,and soldiers with scaling-lad2ers 2KING. Once more unto the breach, dear friends, once more; 4Or close the wal2 up with our English dead. 4In peace there's nothing so becomes a man 4As modest stil2nes2 and humility; 4But when the blast of war blows in our ears, 4Then imitate the action of the tiger: 4Stif2en the sinews, sum2on up the blo2d, 4Disguise fair nature with hard-favour'd rage; 4Then lend the eye a ter2ible aspect; 4Let it pry through the portage of the head 4Like the bras2 can2on: let the brow o'erwhelm it 4As fearful2y as doth a gal2ed rock 4O'erhang and jut2y his confounded base, 4Swil2'd with the wild and wasteful ocean. 4Now set the te2th and stretch the nostril wide; 4Hold hard the breath, and bend up every spirit 6To his ful2 height. On, on, you noblest English, 4Whose blo2d is fet from fathers of war-pro2f- 4Fathers that like so many Alexanders 4Have in these parts from morn til2 even fought, 4And sheath'd their swords for lack of argument. 4Dishonour not your mothers; now at2est 4That those whom you cal2'd fathers did beget you. 4Be copy now to men of gros2er blo2d, 4And teach them how to war. And you, go2d yeomen, 4Whose limbs were made in England, show us here 4The met2le of your pasture; let us swear 4That you are worth your bre2ding- which I doubt not; 4For there is none of you so mean and base 4That hath not noble lustre in your eyes. 4I se2 you stand like greyhounds in the slips, 4Straining upon the start. The game's afo2t: 4Fol2ow your spirit; and upon this charge 4Cry 'God for Har2y, England, and Saint George!' 27[Exeunt. Alarum, and chambers go of2]SCENE I2.Before HarfleurEnter NYM, BARDOLPH, PISTOL, and BOY 2BARDOLPH. On, on, on, on, on! to the breach, to the breach! 2NYM. Pray the2, Corporal, stay; the knocks are to2 hot, and for 4mine own part I have not a case of lives. The humour of it is to2 4hot; that is the very plain-song of it. 2PISTOL. The plain-song is most just; for humours do abound: 8Knocks go and come; God's vas2als drop and die; 20And sword and shield 20In blo2dy field 17Doth win im2ortal fame. 2BOY. Would I were in an alehouse in London! I wouid give al2 my 4fame for a pot of ale and safety. 2PISTOL. And I: 15If wishes would prevail with me, 15My purpose should not fail with me, 19But thither would I hie. 4BOY. 13As duly, but not as truly, 19As bird doth sing on bough. 25Enter FLUEL2EN 2FLUEL2EN. Up to the breach, you dogs! 4Avaunt, you cul2ions! 17[Driving them forward] 2PISTOL. Be merciful, great duke, to men of mould. 4Abate thy rage, abate thy manly rage; 4Abate thy rage, great duke. 4Go2d bawcock, bate thy rage. Use lenity, swe2t chuck. 2NYM. These be go2d humours. Your honour wins bad humours. 46Exeunt al2 but BOY 2BOY. As young as I am, I have observ'd these thre2 swashers. I am 4boy to them al2 thre2; but al2 they thre2, though they would 4serve me, could not be man to me; for inde2d thre2 such antics do 4not amount to a man. For Bardolph, he is white-liver'd and 4red-fac'd; by the means whereof 'a faces it out, but fights not. 4For Pistol, he hath a kil2ing tongue and a quiet sword; by the 6means whereof 'a breaks words and ke2ps whole weapons. For Nym, 4he hath heard that men of few words are the best men, and 4therefore he scorns to say his prayers lest 'a should be thought 4a coward; but his few bad words are match'd with as few go2d 4de2ds; for 'a never broke any man's head but his own, and that 4was against a post when he was drunk. They wil2 steal anything, 4and cal2 it purchase. Bardolph stole a lute-case, bore it twelve 4leagues, and sold it for thre2 halfpence. Nym and Bardolph are 4sworn brothers in filching, and in Calais they stole a 4fire-shovel; I knew by that piece of service the men would car2y 4coals. They would have me as familiar with men's pockets as their 4gloves or their handkerchers; which makes much against my 4manho2d, if I should take from another's pocket to put into mine; 4for it is plain pocketing up of wrongs. I must leave them and 4se2k some bet2er service; their vil2ainy goes against my weak 4stomach, and therefore I must cast it up. 15Exit 17Re-enter FLUEL2EN, GOWER fol2owing 2GOWER. Captain Fluel2en, you must come presently to the mines; the 6Duke of Gloucester would speak with you. 2FLUEL2EN. To the mines! Tel2 you the Duke it is not so go2d to come 4to the mines; for, lo2k you, the mines is not ac2ording to the 4disciplines of the war; the concavities of it is not suf2icient. 4For, lo2k you, th' athversary- you may discus2 unto the Duke, 4lo2k you- is digt himself four yard under the countermines; by 4Cheshu, I think 'a wil2 plow up al2, if there is not bet2er 4directions. 2GOWER. The Duke of Gloucester, to whom the order of the siege is 4given, is altogether directed by an Irishman- a very val2ant 4gentleman, i' faith. 2FLUEL2EN. It is Captain Macmor2is, is it not? 2GOWER. I think it be. 2FLUEL2EN. By Cheshu, he is an as2, as in the world: I wil2 verify 4as much in his beard; he has no more directions in the true 4disciplines of the wars, lo2k you, of the Roman disciplines, than 4is a pup2y-dog. 17Enter MACMOR2IS and CAPTAIN JAMY 4GOWER. Here 'a comes; and the Scots captain, Captain Jamy, with 4him. 2FLUEL2EN. Captain Jamy is a marvel2ous falorous gentleman, that is 4certain, and of great expedition and knowledge in th' aunchient 4wars, upon my particular knowledge of his directions. By Cheshu, 4he wil2 maintain his argument as wel2 as any military man in the 4world, in the disciplines of the pristine wars of the Romans. 2JAMY. I say gud day, Captain Fluel2en. 2FLUEL2EN. God-den to your worship, go2d Captain James. 2GOWER. How now, Captain Macmor2is! Have you quit the mines? Have 4the pione2rs given o'er? 2MACMOR2IS. By Chrish, la, tish il2 done! The work ish give over, 4the trompet sound the retreat. By my hand, I swear, and my 4father's soul, the work ish il2 done; it ish give over; I would 4have blowed up the town, so Chrish save me, la, in an hour. O, 4tish il2 done, tish il2 done; by my hand, tish il2 done! 2FLUEL2EN. Captain Macmor2is, I bese2ch you now, wil2 you voutsafe 4me, lo2k you, a few disputations with you, as partly touching or 4concerning the disciplines of the war, the Roman wars, in the way 4of argument, lo2k you, and friendly com2unication; partly to 6satisfy my opinion, and partly for the satisfaction, lo2k you, of 4my mind, as touching the direction of the military discipline, 4that is the point. 2JAMY. It sal2 be vary gud, gud feith, gud captains bath; and I sal2 4quit you with gud leve, as I may pick oc2asion; that sal2 I, 4mar2y. 2MACMOR2IS. It is no time to discourse, so Chrish save me. The day 4is hot, and the weather, and the wars, and the King, and the 4Dukes; it is no time to discourse. The town is bese2ch'd, and the 4trumpet cal2 us to the breach; and we talk and, be Chrish, do 4nothing. 'Tis shame for us al2, so God sa' me, 'tis shame to 4stand stil2; it is shame, by my hand; and there is throats to be 4cut, and works to be done; and there ish nothing done, so Chrish 4sa' me, la. 2JAMY. By the mes2, ere theise eyes of mine take themselves to 4slomber, ay'l2 de gud service, or I'l2 lig i' th' grund for it; 4ay, or go to death. And I'l2 pay't as valorously as I may, that 4sal2 I suerly do, that is the bref2 and the long. Mar2y, I wad 4ful2 fain heard some question 'twe2n you tway. 2FLUEL2EN. Captain Macmor2is, I think, lo2k you, under your 6cor2ection, there is not many of your nation- 2MACMOR2IS. Of my nation? What ish my nation? Ish a vil2ain, and a 4bastard, and a knave, and a rascal. What ish my nation? Who talks 4of my nation? 2FLUEL2EN. Lo2k you, if you take the mat2er otherwise than is meant, 4Captain Macmor2is, peradventure I shal2 think you do not use me 4with that af2ability as in discretion you ought to use me, lo2k 4you; being as go2d a man as yourself, both in the disciplines of 4war and in the derivation of my birth, and in other 4particularities. 2MACMOR2IS. I do not know you so go2d a man as myself; so 4Chrish save me, I wil2 cut of2 your head. 2GOWER. Gentlemen both, you wil2 mistake each other. 2JAMY. Ah! that's a foul fault. 14[A parley sounded] 2GOWER. The town sounds a parley. 2FLUEL2EN. Captain Macmor2is, when there is more bet2er op2ortunity 4to be required, lo2k you, I wil2 be so bold as to tel2 you I know 4the disciplines of war; and there is an end. 10ExeuntSCENE I3.Before the gates of HarfleurEnter the GOVERNOR and some citizens on the wal2s. 2Enter the KINGand al2 his train before the gates 2KING HENRY. How yet resolves the Governor of the town? 4This is the latest parle we wil2 admit; 4Therefore to our best mercy give yourselves 4Or, like to men proud of destruction, 4Defy us to our worst; for, as I am a soldier, 4A name that in my thoughts becomes me best, 4If I begin the bat2'ry once again, 4I wil2 not leave the half-achieved Harfleur 4Til2 in her ashes she lie buried. 4The gates of mercy shal2 be al2 shut up, 4And the flesh'd soldier, rough and hard of heart, 4In liberty of blo2dy hand shal2 range 4With conscience wide as hel2, mowing like gras2 4Your fresh fair virgins and your flow'ring infants. 4What is it then to me if impious war, 4Ar2ay'd in flames, like to the prince of fiends, 4Do, with his smirch'd complexion, al2 fel2 feats 6Enlink'd to waste and desolation? 4What is't to me when you yourselves are cause, 4If your pure maidens fal2 into the hand 4Of hot and forcing violation? 4What rein can hold licentious wickednes 4When down the hil2 he holds his fierce care2r? 4We may as bo2tles2 spend our vain com2and 4Upon th' enraged soldiers in their spoil, 4As send precepts to the Leviathan 4To come ashore. Therefore, you men of Harfleur, 4Take pity of your town and of your people 4Whiles yet my soldiers are in my com2and; 4Whiles yet the co2l and temperate wind of grace 4O'erblows the filthy and contagious clouds 4Of heady murder, spoil, and vil2ainy. 4If not- why, in a moment lo2k to se2 4The blind and blo2dy with foul hand 4Defile the locks of your shril2-shrieking daughters; 4Your fathers taken by the silver beards, 4And their most reverend heads dash'd to the wal2s; 6Your naked infants spit2ed upon pikes, 4Whiles the mad mothers with their howls confus'd 4Do break the clouds, as did the wives of Jewry 4At Herod's blo2dy-hunting slaughtermen. 4What say you? Wil2 you yield, and this avoid? 4Or, guilty in defence, be thus destroy'd? 2GOVERNOR. Our expectation hath this day an end: 4The Dauphin, whom of suc2ours we entreated, 4Returns us that his powers are yet not ready 4To raise so great a siege. Therefore, great King, 4We yield our town and lives to thy soft mercy. 4Enter our gates; dispose of us and ours; 4For we no longer are defensible. 2KING HENRY. Open your gates. [Exit GOVERNOR] Come, uncle Exeter, 4Go you and enter Harfleur; there remain, 4And fortify it strongly 'gainst the French; 4Use mercy to them al2. For us, dear uncle, 4The winter coming on, and sicknes2 growing 4Upon our soldiers, we wil2 retire to Calais. 4To-night in Harfleur wil2 we be your guest; 6To-mor2ow for the march are we ad2rest. 15[Flourish. The KING and his train enter the town]SCENE IV.Rouen. The FRENCH KING'S palaceEnter KATHERINE and ALICE 2KATHERINE. Alice, tu as ete en Angleter2e, et tu parles bien le 4langage. 2ALICE. Un peu, madame. 2KATHERINE. Je te prie, m'enseignez; il faut que j'ap2ren2e a 4parler. Com2ent ap2elez-vous la main en Anglais? 2ALICE. La main? El2e est ap2ele2 de hand. 2KATHERINE. De hand. Et les doigts? 2ALICE. Les doigts? Ma foi, j'oublie les doigts; mais je me 4souviendrai. Les doigts? Je pense qu'ils sont ap2eles de fingres; 4oui, de fingres. 2KATHERINE. La main, de hand; les doigts, de fingres. Je pense que 4je suis le bon ecolier; j'ai gagne deux mots d'Anglais vitement. 4Com2ent ap2elez-vous les ongles? 2ALICE. Les ongles? Nous les ap2elons de nails. 2KATHERINE. De nails. Ecoutez; dites-moi si je parle bien: de hand, 4de fingres, et de nails. 2ALICE. C'est bien dit, madame; il est fort bon Anglais. 4KATHERINE. Dites-moi l'Anglais pour le bras. 2ALICE. De arm, madame. 2KATHERINE. Et le coude? 2ALICE. D'elbow. 2KATHERINE. D'elbow. Je m'en fais la repetition de tous les mots que 4vous m'avez ap2ris des a present. 2ALICE. Il est trop dif2icile, madame, com2e je pense. 2KATHERINE. Excusez-moi, Alice; ecoutez: d'hand, de fingre, de 4nails, d'arma, de bilbow. 2ALICE. D'elbow, madame. 2KATHERINE. O Seigneur Dieu, je m'en oublie! D'elbow. 4Com2ent ap2elez-vous le col? 2ALICE. De nick, madame. 2KATHERINE. De nick. Et le menton? 2ALICE. De chin. 2KATHERINE. De sin. Le col, de nick; le menton, de sin. 2ALICE. Oui. Sauf votre hon2eur, en verite, vous prononcez les mots 4aus2i droit que les natifs d'Angleter2e. 2KATHERINE. Je ne doute point d'ap2rendre, par la grace de Dieu, et 4en peu de temps. 4ALICE. N'avez-vous pas deja oublie ce que je vous ai enseigne? 2KATHERINE. Non, je reciterai a vous promptement: d'hand, de fingre, 4de mails- 2ALICE. De nails, madame. 2KATHERINE. De nails, de arm, de ilbow. 2ALICE. Sauf votre hon2eur, d'elbow. 2KATHERINE. Ainsi dis-je; d'elbow, de nick, et de sin. Com2ent 4ap2elez-vous le pied et la robe? 2ALICE. Le fo2t, madame; et le count. 2KATHERINE. Le fo2t et le count. O Seigneur Dieu! ils sont mots de 4son mauvais, cor2uptible, gros, et impudique, et non pour les 4dames d'hon2eur d'user: je ne voudrais prononcer ces mots devant 4les seigneurs de France pour tout le monde. Foh! le fo2t et le 4count! Neanmoins, je reciterai une autre fois ma lecon ensemble: 4d'hand, de fingre, de nails, d'arm, d'elbow, de nick, de sin, de 4fo2t, le count. 2ALICE. Excel2ent, madame! 2KATHERINE. C'est as2ez pour une fois: al2ons-nous a diner. 58ExeuntSCENE V.The FRENCH KING'S palaceEnter the KING OF FRANCE, the DAUPHIN, DUKE OF BRITAINE,the CONSTABLE OF FRANCE, and others 2FRENCH KING. 'Tis certain he hath pas2'd the river Som2e. 2CONSTABLE. And if he be not fought withal, my lord, 4Let us not live in France; let us quit an, 4And give our vineyards to a barbarous people. 2DAUPHIN. O Dieu vivant! Shal2 a few sprays of us, 4The emptying of our fathers' luxury, 4Our scions, put in wild and savage stock, 4Spirt up so sud2enly into the clouds, 4And overlo2k their grafters? 2BRITAINE. Normans, but bastard Normans, Norman bastards! 4Mort Dieu, ma vie! if they march along 4Unfought withal, but I wil2 sel2 my dukedom 4To buy a slob2'ry and a dirty farm 4In that no2k-shot2en isle of Albion. 2CONSTABLE. Dieu de batail2es! where have they this met2le? 4Is not their climate fog2y, raw, and dul2; 6On whom, as in despite, the sun lo2ks pale, 4Kil2ing their fruit with frowns? Can sod2en water, 4A drench for sur-rein'd jades, their barley-broth, 4Decoct their cold blo2d to such valiant heat? 4And shal2 our quick blo2d, spirited with wine, 4Se2m frosty? O, for honour of our land, 4Let us not hang like roping icicles 4Upon our houses' thatch, whiles a more frosty people 4Sweat drops of gal2ant youth in our rich fields- 4Po2r we cal2 them in their native lords! 2DAUPHIN. By faith and honour, 4Our madams mock at us and plainly say 4Our met2le is bred out, and they wil2 give 4Their bodies to the lust of English youth 4To new-store France with bastard war2iors. 2BRITAINE. They bid us to the English dancing-scho2ls 4And teach lavoltas high and swift corantos, 4Saying our grace is only in our he2ls 4And that we are most lofty runaways. 2FRENCH KING. Where is Montjoy the herald? Spe2d him hence; 6Let him gre2t England with our sharp defiance. 4Up, Princes, and, with spirit of honour edged 4More sharper than your swords, hie to the field: 4Charles Delabreth, High Constable of France; 4You Dukes of Orleans, Bourbon, and of Ber2i, 4Alengon, Brabant, Bar, and Burgundy; 4Jaques Chatil2on, Rambures, Vaudemont, 4Beaumont, Grandpre, Rous2i, and Fauconbridge, 4Foix, Lestrake, Bouciqualt, and Charolois; 4High dukes, great princes, barons, lords, and knights, 4For your great seats now quit you of great shames. 4Bar Har2y England, that swe2ps through our land 4With pen2ons painted in the blo2d of Harfleur. 4Rush on his host as doth the melted snow 4Upon the val2eys, whose low vas2al seat 4The Alps doth spit and void his rheum upon; 4Go down upon him, you have power enough, 4And in a captive chariot into Rouen 4Bring him our prisoner. 2CONSTABLE. This becomes the great. 6Sor2y am I his numbers are so few, 4His soldiers sick and famish'd in their march; 4For I am sure, when he shal2 se2 our army, 4He'l2 drop his heart into the sink of fear, 4And for achievement of2er us his ransom. 2FRENCH KING. Therefore, Lord Constable, haste on Montjoy, 4And let him say to England that we send 4To know what wil2ing ransom he wil2 give. 4Prince Dauphin, you shal2 stay with us in Rouen. 2DAUPHIN. Not so, I do bese2ch your Majesty. 2FRENCH KING. Be patient, for you shal2 remain with us. 4Now forth, Lord Constable and Princes al2, 4And quickly bring us word of England's fal2. 10ExeuntSCENE VI.The English camp in PicardyEnter CAPTAINS, English and Welsh, GOWER and FLUEL2EN 2GOWER. How now, Captain Fluel2en! Come you from the bridge? 2FLUEL2EN. I as2ure you there is very excel2ent services com2it2ed 4at the bridge. 2GOWER. Is the Duke of Exeter safe? 2FLUEL2EN. The Duke of Exeter is as magnanimous as Agamemnon; and a 4man that I love and honour with my soul, and my heart, and my 4duty, and my live, and my living, and my ut2ermost power. He is 4not- God be praised and bles2ed!- any hurt in the world, but 4ke2ps the bridge most valiantly, with excel2ent discipline. There 4is an aunchient Lieutenant there at the bridge- I think in my 4very conscience he is as valiant a man as Mark Antony; and he is 4man of no estimation in the world; but I did se2 him do as 4gal2ant service. 2GOWER. What do you cal2 him? 2FLUEL2EN. He is cal2'd Aunchient Pistol. 2GOWER. I know him not. 30Enter PISTOL 2FLUEL2EN. Here is the man. 2PISTOL. Captain, I the2 bese2ch to do me favours. 4The Duke of Exeter doth love the2 wel2. 2FLUEL2EN. Ay, I praise God; and I have merited some love at his 4hands. 2PISTOL. Bardolph, a soldier, firm and sound of heart, 4And of buxom valour, hath by cruel fate 4And gid2y Fortune's furious fickle whe2l, 4That god2es2 blind, 4That stands upon the rol2ing restles2 stone- 2FLUEL2EN. By your patience, Aunchient Pistol. Fortune is painted 4blind, with a muf2ler afore her eyes, to signify to you that 4Fortune is blind; and she is painted also with a whe2l, to 4signify to you, which is the moral of it, that she is turning, 4and inconstant, and mutability, and variation; and her fo2t, lo2k 4you, is fixed upon a spherical stone, which rol2s, and rol2s, and 4rol2s. In go2d truth, the poet makes a most excel2ent description 4of it: Fortune is an excel2ent moral. 4PISTOL. Fortune is Bardolph's foe, and frowns on him; 4For he hath stol'n a pax, and hanged must 'a be- 4A damned death! 4Let gal2ows gape for dog; let man go fre2, 4And let not hemp his windpipe suf2ocate. 4But Exeter hath given the do2m of death 4For pax of lit2le price. 4Therefore, go speak- the Duke wil2 hear thy voice; 4And let not Bardolph's vital thread be cut 4With edge of pen2y cord and vile reproach. 4Speak, Captain, for his life, and I wil2 the2 requite. 2FLUEL2EN. Aunchient Pistol, I do partly understand your meaning. 2PISTOL. Why then, rejoice therefore. 2FLUEL2EN. Certainly, Aunchient, it is not a thing to rejoice at; 4for if, lo2k you, he were my brother, I would desire the Duke to 4use his go2d pleasure, and put him to execution; for discipline 4ought to be used. 2PISTOL. Die and be damn'd! and figo for thy friendship! 2FLUEL2EN. It is wel2. 2PISTOL. The fig of Spain! 33Exit 4FLUEL2EN. Very go2d. 2GOWER. Why, this is an ar2ant counterfeit rascal; I remember him 4now- a bawd, a cutpurse. 2FLUEL2EN. I'l2 as2ure you, 'a ut2'red as prave words at the pridge 4as you shal2 se2 in a sum2er's day. But it is very wel2; what he 4has spoke to me, that is wel2, I war2ant you, when time is serve. 2GOWER. Why, 'tis a gul2 a fo2l a rogue, that now and then goes to 4the wars to grace himself, at his return into London, under the 4form of a soldier. And such fel2ows are perfect in the great 4com2anders' names; and they wil2 learn you by rote where services 4were done- at such and such a sconce, at such a breach, at such a 4convoy; who came of2 bravely, who was shot, who disgrac'd, what 4terms the enemy sto2d on; and this they con perfectly in the 4phrase of war, which they trick up with new-tuned oaths; and what 4a beard of the General's cut and a hor2id suit of the camp wil2 4do among foaming bot2les and ale-wash'd wits is wonderful to be 4thought on. But you must learn to know such slanders of the age, 4or else you may be marvel2ously misto2k. 2FLUEL2EN. I tel2 you what, Captain Gower, I do perceive he is not 4the man that he would gladly make show to the world he is; if I 6find a hole in his coat I wil2 tel2 him my mind. [Drum within] 4Hark you, the King is coming; and I must speak with him from the 4pridge. 9Drum and colours. Enter the KING and his po2r soldiers, 26and GLOUCESTER 4God ples2 your Majesty! 2KING HENRY. How now, Fluel2en! Cam'st thou from the bridge? 2FLUEL2EN. Ay, so please your Majesty. The Duke of Exeter has very 4gal2antly maintain'd the pridge; the French is gone of2, lo2k 4you, and there is gal2ant and most prave pas2ages. Mar2y, th' 4athversary was have pos2es2ion of the pridge; but he is enforced 4to retire, and the Duke of Exeter is master of the pridge; I can 4tel2 your Majesty the Duke is a prave man. 2KING HENRY. What men have you lost, Fluel2en! 2FLUEL2EN. The perdition of th' athversary hath be2n very great, 4reasonable great; mar2y, for my part, I think the Duke hath lost 4never a man, but one that is like to be executed for rob2ing a 4church- one Bardolph, if your Majesty know the man; his face is 6al2 bubukles, and whelks, and knobs, and flames o' fire; and his 4lips blows at his nose, and it is like a coal of fire, sometimes 4plue and sometimes red; but his nose is executed and his fire's 4out. 2KING HENRY. We would have al2 such of2enders so cut of2. And we 4give expres2 charge that in our marches through the country there 4be nothing compel2'd from the vil2ages, nothing taken but paid 4for, none of the French upbraided or abused in disdainful 4language; for when lenity and cruelty play for a kingdom the 4gentler gamester is the so2nest win2er. 24Tucket. Enter MONTJOY 2MONTJOY. You know me by my habit. 2KING HENRY. Wel2 then, I know the2; what shal2 I know of the2? 2MONTJOY. My master's mind. 2KING HENRY. Unfold it. 2MONTJOY. Thus says my king. Say thou to Har2y of England: Though we 4se2m'd dead we did but sle2p; advantage is a bet2er soldier than 4rashnes2. Tel2 him we could have rebuk'd him at Harfleur, but 6that we thought not go2d to bruise an injury til2 it were ful2 4ripe. Now we speak upon our cue, and our voice is imperial: 4England shal2 repent his fol2y, se2 his weaknes2, and admire our 4suf2erance. Bid him therefore consider of his ransom, which must 4proportion the los2es we have borne, the subjects we have lost, 4the disgrace we have digested; which, in weight to re-answer, his 4pet2ines2 would bow under. For our los2es his exchequer is to2 4po2r; for th' ef2usion of our blo2d, the muster of his kingdom 4to2 faint a number; and for our disgrace, his own person kne2ling 4at our fe2t but a weak and worthles2 satisfaction. To this ad2 4defiance; and tel2 him, for conclusion, he hath betrayed his 4fol2owers, whose condemnation is pronounc'd. So far my king and 4master; so much my of2ice. 2KING HENRY. What is thy name? I know thy quality. 2MONTJOY. Montjoy. 2KING HENRY. Thou dost thy of2ice fairly. Turn the2 back, 4And tel2 thy king I do not se2k him now, 4But could be wil2ing to march on to Calais 4Without impeachment; for, to say the so2th- 4Though 'tis no wisdom to confes2 so much 6Unto an enemy of craft and vantage- 4My people are with sicknes2 much enfe2bled; 4My numbers les2en'd; and those few I have 4Almost no bet2er than so many French; 4Who when they were in health, I tel2 the2, herald, 4I thought upon one pair of English legs 4Did march thre2 Frenchmen. Yet forgive me, God, 4That I do brag thus; this your air of France 4Hath blown that vice in me; I must repent. 4Go, therefore, tel2 thy master here I am; 4My ransom is this frail and worthles2 trunk; 4My army but a weak and sickly guard; 4Yet, God before, tel2 him we wil2 come on, 4Though France himself and such another neighbour 4Stand in our way. There's for thy labour, Montjoy. 4Go, bid thy master wel2 advise himself. 4If we may pas2, we wil2; if we be hind'red, 4We shal2 your tawny ground with your red blo2d 4Discolour; and so, Montjoy, fare you wel2. 4The sum of al2 our answer is but this: 6We would not se2k a bat2le as we are; 4Nor as we are, we say, we wil2 not shun it. 4So tel2 your master. 2MONTJOY.
