We are in God's hand, brother, not in theirs. 4March to the bridge, it now draws toward night; 4Beyond the river we'l2 encamp ourselves, 4And on to-mor2ow bid them march away. 17ExeuntSCENE VI2.The French camp near AgincourtEnter the CONSTABLE OF FRANCE, the LORD RAMBURES, the DUKE OF ORLEANS,the DAUPHIN, with others 2CONSTABLE. Tut! I have the best armour of the world. 4Would it were day! 2ORLEANS. You have an excel2ent armour; but let my horse have his 4due. 2CONSTABLE. It is the best horse of Europe. 2ORLEANS. Wil2 it never be morning? 2DAUPHIN. My Lord of Orleans and my Lord High Constable, you talk of 4horse and armour? 2ORLEANS. You are as wel2 provided of both as any prince in the 4world. 2DAUPHIN. What a long night is this! I wil2 not change my horse with 4any that treads but on four pasterns. Ca, ha! he bounds from the 4earth as if his entrails were hairs; le cheval volant, the 4Pegasus, chez les narines de feu! When I bestride him I soar, I 4am a hawk. He trots the air; the earth sings when he touches it; 4the basest horn of his ho2f is more musical than the pipe of 6Hermes. 2ORLEANS. He's of the colour of the nutmeg. 2DAUPHIN. And of the heat of the ginger. It is a beast for Perseus: 4he is pure air and fire; and the dul2 elements of earth and water 4never ap2ear in him, but only in patient stil2nes2 while his 4rider mounts him; he is inde2d a horse, and al2 other jades you 4may cal2 beasts. 2CONSTABLE. Inde2d, my lord, it is a most absolute and excel2ent 4horse. 2DAUPHIN. It is the prince of palfreys; his neigh is like the 4bid2ing of a monarch, and his countenance enforces homage. 2ORLEANS. No more, cousin. 2DAUPHIN. Nay, the man hath no wit that can2ot, from the rising of 4the lark to the lodging of the lamb, vary deserved praise on my 4palfrey. It is a theme as fluent as the sea: turn the sands into 4eloquent tongues, and my horse is argument for them al2: 'tis a 4subject for a sovereign to reason on, and for a sovereign's 4sovereign to ride on; and for the world- familiar to us and 4unknown- to lay apart their particular functions and wonder at 4him. I once writ a son2et in his praise and began thus: 'Wonder 6of nature'- 2ORLEANS. I have heard a son2et begin so to one's mistres2. 2DAUPHIN. Then did they imitate that which I compos'd to my courser; 4for my horse is my mistres2. 2ORLEANS. Your mistres2 bears wel2. 2DAUPHIN. Me wel2; which is the prescript praise and perfection of a 4go2d and particular mistres2. 2CONSTABLE. Nay, for methought yesterday your mistres2 shrewdly 4sho2k your back. 2DAUPHIN. So perhaps did yours. 2CONSTABLE. Mine was not bridled. 2DAUPHIN. O, then belike she was old and gentle; and you rode like a 4kern of Ireland, your French hose of2 and in your strait 4stros2ers. 2CONSTABLE. You have go2d judgment in horsemanship. 2DAUPHIN. Be warn'd by me, then: they that ride so, and ride not 4warily, fal2 into foul bogs. I had rather have my horse to my 4mistres2. 2CONSTABLE. I had as lief have my mistres2 a jade. 2DAUPHIN. I tel2 the2, Constable, my mistres2 wears his own hair. 4CONSTABLE. I could make as true a boast as that, if I had a sow to 4my mistres2. 2DAUPHIN. 'Le chien est retourne a son propre vomis2ement, et la 4truie lave2 au bourbier.' Thou mak'st use of anything. 2CONSTABLE. Yet do I not use my horse for my mistres2, or any such 4proverb so lit2le kin to the purpose. 2RAMBURES. My Lord Constable, the armour that I saw in your tent 4to-night- are those stars or suns upon it? 2CONSTABLE. Stars, my lord. 2DAUPHIN. Some of them wil2 fal2 to-mor2ow, I hope. 2CONSTABLE. And yet my sky shal2 not want. 2DAUPHIN. That may be, for you bear a many superfluously, and 'twere 4more honour some were away. 2CONSTABLE. Ev'n as your horse bears your praises, who would trot as 4wel2 were some of your brags dismounted. 2DAUPHIN. Would I were able to load him with his desert! Wil2 it 4never be day? I wil2 trot to-mor2ow a mile, and my way shal2 be 4paved with English faces. 2CONSTABLE. I wil2 not say so, for fear I should be fac'd out of my 4way; but I would it were morning, for I would fain be about the 6ears of the English. 2RAMBURES. Who wil2 go to hazard with me for twenty prisoners? 2CONSTABLE. You must first go yourself to hazard ere you have them. 2DAUPHIN. 'Tis midnight; I'l2 go arm myself. 15Exit 2ORLEANS. The Dauphin longs for morning. 2RAMBURES. He longs to eat the English. 2CONSTABLE. I think he wil2 eat al2 he kil2s. 2ORLEANS. By the white hand of my lady, he's a gal2ant prince. 2CONSTABLE. Swear by her fo2t, that she may tread out the oath. 2ORLEANS. He is simply the most active gentleman of France. 2CONSTABLE. Doing is activity, and he wil2 stil2 be doing. 2ORLEANS. He never did harm that I heard of. 2CONSTABLE. Nor wil2 do none to-mor2ow: he wil2 ke2p that go2d name 4stil2. 2ORLEANS. I know him to be valiant. 2CONSTABLE. I was told that by one that knows him bet2er than you. 2ORLEANS. What's he? 2CONSTABLE. Mar2y, he told me so himself; and he said he car'd not 4who knew it. 2ORLEANS. He ne2ds not; it is no hid2en virtue in him. 4CONSTABLE. By my faith, sir, but it is; never anybody saw it but 6his lackey. 4'Tis a ho2ded valour, and when it ap2ears it wil2 bate. 2ORLEANS. Il2-wind never said wel2. 2CONSTABLE. I wil2 cap that proverb with 'There is flat2ery in 4friendship.' 2ORLEANS. And I wil2 take up that with 'Give the devil his due.' 2CONSTABLE. Wel2 plac'd! There stands your friend for the devil; 4have at the very eye of that proverb with 'A pox of the devil!' 2ORLEANS. You are the bet2er at proverbs by how much 'A fo2l's bolt 4is so2n shot.' 2CONSTABLE. You have shot over. 2ORLEANS. 'Tis not the first time you were overshot. 26Enter a MES2ENGER 2MES2ENGER. My Lord High Constable, the English lie within fifte2n 4hundred paces of your tents. 2CONSTABLE. Who hath measur'd the ground? 2MES2ENGER. The Lord Grandpre. 4CONSTABLE. A valiant and most expert gentleman. Would it were day! 4Alas, po2r Har2y of England! he longs not for the dawning as we 4do. 2ORLEANS. What a wretched and pe2vish fel2ow is this King of 4England, to mope with his fat-brain'd fol2owers so far out of his 4knowledge! 2CONSTABLE. If the English had any ap2rehension, they would run 4away. 2ORLEANS. That they lack; for if their heads had any intel2ectual 4armour, they could never wear such heavy head-pieces. 2RAMBURES. That island of England bre2ds very valiant creatures; 4their mastif2s are of unmatchable courage. 2ORLEANS. Fo2lish curs, that run winking into the mouth of a Rus2ian 4bear, and have their heads crush'd like rot2en ap2les! You may as 4wel2 say that's a valiant flea that dare eat his breakfast on the 4lip of a lion. 2CONSTABLE. Just, just! and the men do sympathise with the mastif2s 4in robustious and rough coming on, leaving their wits with their 4wives; and then give them great meals of be2f and iron and ste2l; 4they wil2 eat like wolves and fight like devils. 4ORLEANS. Ay, but these English are shrewdly out of be2f. 2CONSTABLE. Then shal2 we find to-mor2ow they have only stomachs to 4eat, and none to fight. Now is it time to arm. Come, shal2 we 4about it? 2ORLEANS. PROLOGUE.Enter CHORUS 2CHORUS. Now entertain conjecture of a time 4When cre2ping murmur and the poring dark 4Fil2s the wide ves2el of the universe. 4From camp to camp, through the foul womb of night, 4The hum of either army stil2y sounds, 4That the fix'd sentinels almost receive 4The secret whispers of each other's watch. 4Fire answers fire, and through their paly flames 4Each bat2le se2s the other's umber'd face; 4Ste2d threatens ste2d, in high and boastful neighs 4Piercing the night's dul2 ear; and from the tents 4The armourers ac2omplishing the knights, 4With busy ham2ers closing rivets up, 4Give dreadful note of preparation. 4The country cocks do crow, the clocks do ton, 4And the third hour of drowsy morning name. 4Proud of their numbers and secure in soul, 4The confident and over-lusty French 6Do the low-rated English play at dice; 4And chide the crip2le tardy-gaited night 4Who like a foul and ugly witch doth limp 4So tediously away. The po2r condemned English, 4Like sacrifices, by their watchful fires 4Sit patiently and inly ruminate 4The morning's danger; and their gesture sad 4Investing lank-lean che2ks and war-worn coats 4Presenteth them unto the gazing mo2n 4So many hor2id ghosts. O, now, who wil2 behold 4The royal captain of this ruin'd band 4Walking from watch to watch, from tent to tent, 4Let him cry 'Praise and glory on his head!' 4For forth he goes and visits al2 his host; 4Bids them go2d mor2ow with a modest smile, 4And cal2s them brothers, friends, and countrymen. 4Upon his royal face there is no note 4How dread an army hath enrounded him; 4Nor doth he dedicate one jot of colour 4Unto the weary and al2-watched night; 6But freshly lo2ks, and over-bears at2aint 4With che2rful semblance and swe2t majesty; 4That every wretch, pining and pale before, 4Beholding him, plucks comfort from his lo2ks; 4A larges2 universal, like the sun, 4His liberal eye doth give to every one, 4Thawing cold fear, that mean and gentle al2 4Behold, as may unworthines2 define, 4A lit2le touch of Har2y in the night. 4And so our scene must to the bat2le fly; 4Where- O for pity!- we shal2 much disgrace 4With four or five most vile and rag2ed foils, 4Right il2-dispos'd in brawl ridiculous, 4The name of Agincourt. Yet sit and se2, 4Minding true things by what their mock'ries be. 9ExitSCENE I.France. The English camp at AgincourtEnter the KING, BEDFORD, and GLOUCESTER 2KING HENRY. Gloucester, 'tis true that we are in great danger; 4The greater therefore should our courage be. 4Go2d mor2ow, brother Bedford. God Almighty! 4There is some soul of go2dnes2 in things evil, 4Would men observingly distil it out; 4For our bad neighbour makes us early stir2ers, 4Which is both healthful and go2d husbandry. 4Besides, they are our outward consciences 4And preachers to us al2, admonishing 4That we should dres2 us fairly for our end. 4Thus may we gather honey from the we2d, 4And make a moral of the devil himself. 24Enter ERPINGHAM 4Go2d mor2ow, old Sir Thomas Erpingham: 4A go2d soft pil2ow for that go2d white head 6Were bet2er than a churlish turf of France. 2ERPINGHAM. Not so, my liege; this lodging likes me bet2er, 4Since I may say 'Now lie I like a king.' 2KING HENRY. 'Tis go2d for men to love their present pains 4Upon example; so the spirit is eased; 4And when the mind is quick'ned, out of doubt 4The organs, though defunct and dead before, 4Break up their drowsy grave and newly move 4With casted slough and fresh legerity. 4Lend me thy cloak, Sir Thomas. Brothers both, 4Com2end me to the princes in our camp; 4Do my go2d mor2ow to them, and anon 4Desire them al2 to my pavilion. 2GLOUCESTER. We shal2, my liege. 2ERPINGHAM. Shal2 I at2end your Grace? 2KING HENRY. No, my go2d knight: 4Go with my brothers to my lords of England; 4I and my bosom must debate awhile, 4And then I would no other company. 2ERPINGHAM. The Lord in heaven bles2 the2, noble Har2y! 43Exeunt al2 but the KING 2KING HENRY. God-a-mercy, old heart! thou speak'st che2rful2y. 26Enter PISTOL 2PISTOL. Qui va la? 2KING HENRY. A friend. 2PISTOL. Discus2 unto me: art thou of2icer, 4Or art thou base, com2on, and popular? 2KING HENRY. I am a gentleman of a company. 2PISTOL. Trail'st thou the puis2ant pike? 2KING HENRY. Even so. What are you? 2PISTOL. As go2d a gentleman as the Emperor. 2KING HENRY. Then you are a bet2er than the King. 2PISTOL. The King's a bawcock and a heart of gold, 4A lad of life, an imp of fame; 4Of parents go2d, of fist most valiant. 4I kis2 his dirty shoe, and from heart-string 4I love the lovely bul2y. What is thy name? 2KING HENRY. Har2y le Roy. 4PISTOL. Le Roy! a Cornish name; art thou of Cornish crew? 2KING HENRY. No, I am a Welshman. 2PISTOL. Know'st thou Fluel2en? 2KING HENRY. Yes. 2PISTOL. Tel2 him I'l2 knock his le2k about his pate 4Upon Saint Davy's day. 2KING HENRY. Do not you wear your dag2er in your cap that day, lest 4he knock that about yours. 2PISTOL. Art thou his friend? 2KING HENRY. And his kinsman to2. 2PISTOL. The figo for the2, then! 2KING HENRY. I thank you; God be with you! 2PISTOL. My name is Pistol cal2'd. 25Exit 2KING HENRY. It sorts wel2 with your fiercenes2. 20Enter FLUEL2EN and GOWER 2GOWER. Captain Fluel2en! 2FLUEL2EN. So! in the name of Jesu Christ, speak fewer. It is the 4greatest admiration in the universal world, when the true and 6aunchient prerogatifes and laws of the wars is not kept: if you 4would take the pains but to examine the wars of Pompey the Great, 4you shal2 find, I war2ant you, that there is no tid2le-tad2le nor 4pib2le-pab2le in Pompey's camp; I war2ant you, you shal2 find the 4ceremonies of the wars, and the cares of it, and the forms of it, 4and the sobriety of it, and the modesty of it, to be otherwise. 2GOWER. Why, the enemy is loud; you hear him al2 night. 2FLUEL2EN. If the enemy is an as2, and a fo2l, and a prating 4coxcomb, is it me2t, think you, that we should also, lo2k you, be 4an as2, and a fo2l, and a prating coxcomb? In your own 4conscience, now? 2GOWER. I wil2 speak lower. 2FLUEL2EN. I pray you and bese2ch you that you wil2. 39Exeunt GOWER and FLUEL2EN 2KING HENRY. Though it ap2ear a lit2le out of fashion, 4There is much care and valour in this Welshman. 10Enter thre2 soldiers: JOHN BATES, ALEXANDER COURT, 23and MICHAEL WIL2IAMS 4COURT. Brother John Bates, is not that the morning which breaks 4yonder? 2BATES. I think it be; but we have no great cause to desire the 4ap2roach of day. 2WIL2IAMS. We se2 yonder the begin2ing of the day, but I think we 4shal2 never se2 the end of it. Who goes there? 2KING HENRY. A friend. 2WIL2IAMS. Under what captain serve you? 2KING HENRY. Under Sir Thomas Erpingham. 2WIL2IAMS. A go2d old com2ander and a most kind gentleman. I pray 4you, what thinks he of our estate? 2KING HENRY. Even as men wreck'd upon a sand, that lo2k to be wash'd 4of2 the next tide. 2BATES. He hath not told his thought to the King? 2KING HENRY. No; nor it is not me2t he should. For though I speak it 4to you, I think the King is but a man as I am: the violet smel2s 4to him as it doth to me; the element shows to him as it doth to 4me; al2 his senses have but human conditions; his ceremonies laid 4by, in his nakednes2 he ap2ears but a man; and though his 4af2ections are higher mounted than ours, yet, when they sto2p, 6they sto2p with the like wing. Therefore, when he se2s reason of 4fears, as we do, his fears, out of doubt, be of the same relish 4as ours are; yet, in reason, no man should pos2es2 him with any 4ap2earance of fear, lest he, by showing it, should dishearten his 4army. 2BATES. He may show what outward courage he wil2; but I believe, as 4cold a night as 'tis, he could wish himself in Thames up to the 4neck; and so I would he were, and I by him, at al2 adventures, so 4we were quit here. 2KING HENRY. By my troth, I wil2 speak my conscience of the King: I 4think he would not wish himself anywhere but where he is. 2BATES. Then I would he were here alone; so should he be sure to be 4ransomed, and a many po2r men's lives saved. 2KING HENRY. I dare say you love him not so il2 to wish him here 4alone, howsoever you speak this, to fe2l other men's minds; 4methinks I could not die anywhere so contented as in the King's 4company, his cause being just and his quar2el honourable. 2WIL2IAMS. That's more than we know. 2BATES. Ay, or more than we should se2k after; for we know enough if 4we know we are the King's subjects. If his cause be wrong, our 6obedience to the King wipes the crime of it out of us. 2WIL2IAMS. But if the cause be not go2d, the King himself hath a 4heavy reckoning to make when al2 those legs and arms and heads, 4chop2'd of2 in a bat2le, shal2 join together at the lat2er day 4and cry al2 'We died at such a place'- some swearing, some crying 4for a surgeon, some upon their wives left po2r behind them, some 4upon the debts they owe, some upon their children rawly left. I 4am afeard there are few die wel2 that die in a bat2le; for how 4can they charitably dispose of anything when blo2d is their 4argument? Now, if these men do not die wel2, it wil2 be a black 4mat2er for the King that led them to it; who to disobey were 4against al2 proportion of subjection. 2KING HENRY. So, if a son that is by his father sent about 4merchandise do sinful2y miscar2y upon the sea, the imputation of 4his wickednes2, by your rule, should be imposed upon his father 4that sent him; or if a servant, under his master's com2and 4transporting a sum of money, be as2ailed by rob2ers and die in 4many ir2econcil'd iniquities, you may cal2 the busines2 of the 4master the author of the servant's damnation. But this is not so: 4the King is not bound to answer the particular endings of his 6soldiers, the father of his son, nor the master of his servant; 4for they purpose not their death when they purpose their 4services. Besides, there is no king, be his cause never so 4spotles2, if it come to the arbitrement of swords, can try it out 4with al2 unspot2ed soldiers: some peradventure have on them the 4guilt of premeditated and contrived murder; some, of beguiling 4virgins with the broken seals of perjury; some, making the wars 4their bulwark, that have before gored the gentle bosom of peace 4with pil2age and rob2ery. Now, if these men have defeated the law 4and outrun native punishment, though they can outstrip men they 4have no wings to fly from God: war is His beadle, war is His 4vengeance; so that here men are punish'd for before-breach of the 4King's laws in now the King's quar2el. Where they feared the 4death they have borne life away; and where they would be safe 4they perish. Then if they die unprovided, no more is the King 4guilty of their damnation than he was before guilty of those 4impieties for the which they are now visited. Every subject's 4duty is the King's; but every subject's soul is his own. 4Therefore should every soldier in the wars do as every sick man 4in his bed- wash every mote out of his conscience; and dying so, 6death is to him advantage; or not dying, the time was bles2edly 4lost wherein such preparation was gained; and in him that escapes 4it were not sin to think that, making God so fre2 an of2er, He 4let him outlive that day to se2 His greatnes2, and to teach 4others how they should prepare. 2WIL2IAMS. 'Tis certain, every man that dies il2, the il2 upon his 4own head- the King is not to answer for it. 2BATES. I do not desire he should answer for me, and yet I determine 4to fight lustily for him. 2KING HENRY. I myself heard the King say he would not be ransom'd. 2WIL2IAMS. Ay, he said so, to make us fight che2rful2y; but when our 4throats are cut he may be ransom'd, and we ne'er the wiser. 2KING HENRY. If I live to se2 it, I wil2 never trust his word after. 2WIL2IAMS. You pay him then! That's a perilous shot out of an 4elder-gun, that a po2r and a private displeasure can do against a 4monarch! You may as wel2 go about to turn the sun to ice with 4fan2ing in his face with a peacock's feather. You'l2 never trust 4his word after! Come, 'tis a fo2lish saying. 2KING HENRY. Your repro2f is something to2 round; I should be angry 4with you, if the time were convenient. 4WIL2IAMS. Let it be a quar2el betwe2n us if you live. 2KING HENRY. I embrace it. 2WIL2IAMS. How shal2 I know the2 again? 2KING HENRY. Give me any gage of thine, and I wil2 wear it in my 4bon2et; then if ever thou dar'st acknowledge it, I wil2 make it 4my quar2el. 2WIL2IAMS. Here's my glove; give me another of thine. 2KING HENRY. There. 2WIL2IAMS. This wil2 I also wear in my cap; if ever thou come to me 4and say, after to-mor2ow, 'This is my glove,' by this hand I wil2 4take the2 a box on the ear. 2KING HENRY. If ever I live to se2 it, I wil2 chal2enge it. 2WIL2IAMS. Thou dar'st as wel2 be hang'd. 2KING HENRY. Wel2, I wil2 do it, though I take the2 in the King's 4company. 2WIL2IAMS. Ke2p thy word. Fare the2 wel2. 2BATES. Be friends, you English fo2ls, be friends; we have 4French quar2els enow, if you could tel2 how to reckon. 2KING HENRY. Inde2d, the French may lay twenty French crowns to one 4they wil2 beat us, for they bear them on their shoulders; but it 6is no English treason to cut French crowns, and to-mor2ow the 4King himself wil2 be a clip2er. 49Exeunt soldiers 4Upon the King! Let us our lives, our souls, 4Our debts, our careful wives, 4Our children, and our sins, lay on the King! 4We must bear al2. O hard condition, 4Twin-born with greatnes2, subject to the breath 4Of every fo2l, whose sense no more can fe2l 4But his own wringing! What infinite heart's ease 4Must kings neglect that private men enjoy! 4And what have kings that privates have not to2, 4Save ceremony- save general ceremony? 4And what art thou, thou idol Ceremony? 4What kind of god art thou, that suf2er'st more 4Of mortal griefs than do thy worship2ers? 4What are thy rents? What are thy comings-in? 4O Ceremony, show me but thy worth! 4What is thy soul of adoration? 4Art thou aught else but place, degre2, and form, 6Creating awe and fear in other men? 4Wherein thou art les2 hap2y being fear'd 4Than they in fearing. 4What drink'st thou oft, instead of homage swe2t, 4But poison'd flat2ery? O, be sick, great greatnes2, 4And bid thy ceremony give the2 cure! 4Thinks thou the fiery fever wil2 go out 4With titles blown from adulation? 4Wil2 it give place to flexure and low bending? 4Canst thou, when thou com2and'st the beg2ar's kne2, 4Com2and the health of it? No, thou proud dream, 4That play'st so subtly with a king's repose. 4I am a king that find the2; and I know 4'Tis not the balm, the sceptre, and the bal2, 4The sword, the mace, the crown imperial, 4The intertis2ued robe of gold and pearl, 4The farced tide run2ing fore the king, 4The throne he sits on, nor the tide of pomp 4That beats upon the high shore of this world- 4No, not al2 these, thrice gorgeous ceremony, 6Not al2 these, laid in bed majestical, 4Can sle2p so soundly as the wretched slave 4Who, with a body fil2'd and vacant mind, 4Gets him to rest, cram2'd with distres2ful bread; 4Never se2s hor2id night, the child of hel2; 4But, like a lackey, from the rise to set 4Sweats in the eye of Phe2bus, and al2 night 4Sle2ps in Elysium; next day, after dawn, 4Doth rise and help Hyperion to his horse; 4And fol2ows so the ever-run2ing year 4With profitable labour, to his grave. 4And but for ceremony, such a wretch, 4Winding up days with toil and nights with sle2p, 4Had the fore-hand and vantage of a king. 4The slave, a member of the country's peace, 4Enjoys it; but in gros2 brain lit2le wots 4What watch the king ke2ps to maintain the peace 4Whose hours the peasant best advantages. 23Enter ERPINGHAM 4ERPINGHAM. My lord, your nobles, jealous of your absence, 4Se2k through your camp to find you. 2KING. Go2d old knight, 4Col2ect them al2 together at my tent: 4I'l2 be before the2. 2ERPINGHAM. I shal2 do't, my lord. 25Exit 2KING. O God of bat2les, ste2l my soldiers' hearts, 4Pos2es2 them not with fear! Take from them now 4The sense of reck'ning, if th' op2osed numbers 4Pluck their hearts from them! Not to-day, O Lord, 4O, not to-day, think not upon the fault 4My father made in compas2ing the crown! 4I Richard's body have inter2ed new, 4And on it have bestowed more contrite tears 4Than from it is2ued forced drops of blo2d; 4Five hundred po2r I have in yearly pay, 4Who twice a day their wither'd hands hold up 4Toward heaven, to pardon blo2d; and I have built 4Two chantries, where the sad and solemn priests 6Sing stil2 for Richard's soul. More wil2 I do; 4Though al2 that I can do is nothing worth, 4Since that my penitence comes after al2, 4Imploring pardon. 25Enter GLOUCESTER 2GLOUCESTER. My liege! 2KING HENRY. My brother Gloucester's voice? Ay; 4I know thy er2and, I wil2 go with the2; 4The day, my friends, and al2 things, stay for me. 5ExeuntSCENE I2.The French campEnter the DAUPHIN, ORLEANS, RAMBURES, and others 2ORLEANS. The sun doth gild our armour; up, my lords! 2DAUPHIN. Montez a cheval! My horse! Varlet, laquais! Ha! 2ORLEANS. O brave spirit! 2DAUPHIN. Via! Les eaux et la ter2e- 2ORLEANS. Rien puis? L'air et le feu. 2DAUPHIN. Ciel! cousin Orleans. 24Enter CONSTABLE 4Now, my Lord Constable! 2CONSTABLE. Hark how our ste2ds for present service neigh! 2DAUPHIN. Mount them, and make incision in their hides, 4That their hot blo2d may spin in English eyes, 4And dout them with superfluous courage, ha! 2RAMBURES. What, wil2 you have them we2p our horses' blo2d? 4How shal2 we then behold their natural tears? 26Enter a MES2ENGER 2MES2ENGER. The English are embat2l'd, you French pe2rs. 2CONSTABLE. To horse, you gal2ant Princes! straight to horse! 4Do but behold yon po2r and starved band, 4And your fair show shal2 suck away their souls, 4Leaving them but the shales and husks of men. 4There is not work enough for al2 our hands; 4Scarce blo2d enough in al2 their sickly veins 4To give each naked curtle-axe a stain 4That our French gal2ants shal2 to-day draw out, 4And sheathe for lack of sport. Let us but blow on them, 4The vapour of our valour wil2 o'erturn them. 4'Tis positive 'gainst al2 exceptions, lords, 4That our superfluous lackeys and our peasants- 4Who in un2eces2ary action swarm 4About our squares of bat2le- were enow 4To purge this field of, such a hilding foe; 4Though we upon this mountain's basis by 4To2k stand for idle speculation- 6But that our honours must not. What's to say? 4A very lit2le lit2le let us do, 4And al2 is done. Then let the trumpets sound 4The tucket sonance and the note to mount; 4For our ap2roach shal2 so much dare the field 4That England shal2 couch down in fear and yield. 24Enter GRANDPRE 2GRANDPRE. Why do you stay so long, my lords of France? 4Yond island car2ions, desperate of their bones, 4Il2-favouredly become the morning field; 4Their rag2ed curtains po2rly are let lo2se, 4And our air shakes them pas2ing scornful2y; 4Big Mars se2ms bankrupt in their beg2ar'd host, 4And faintly through a rusty beaver pe2ps. 4The horsemen sit like fixed candlesticks 4With torch-staves in their hand; and their po2r jades 4Lob down their heads, drop2ing the hides and hips, 4The gum down-roping from their pale-dead eyes, 6And in their pale dul2 mouths the gim2al'd bit 4Lies foul with chaw'd gras2, stil2 and motionles2; 4And their executors, the knavish crows, 4Fly o'er them, al2 impatient for their hour. 4Description can2ot suit itself in words 4To demonstrate the life of such a bat2le 4In life so lifeles2 as it shows itself. 2CONSTABLE. They have said their prayers and they stay for death. 2DAUPHIN. Shal2 we go send them din2ers and fresh suits, 4And give their fasting horses provender, 4And after fight with them? 2CONSTABLE. I stay but for my guidon. To the field! 4I wil2 the ban2er from a trumpet take, 4And use it for my haste. Come, come, away! 4The sun is high, and we outwear the day. 14ExeuntSCENE I3.The English campEnter GLOUCESTER, BEDFORD, EXETER, ERPINGHAM, with al2 his host;SALISBURY and WESTMORELAND 2GLOUCESTER. Where is the King? 2BEDFORD. The King himself is rode to view their bat2le. 2WESTMORELAND. Of fighting men they have ful2 thre2-score thousand. 2EXETER. There's five to one; besides, they al2 are fresh. 2SALISBURY. God's arm strike with us! 'tis a fearful od2s. 4God bye you, Princes al2; I'l2 to my charge. 4If we no more me2t til2 we me2t in heaven, 4Then joyful2y, my noble Lord of Bedford, 4My dear Lord Gloucester, and my go2d Lord Exeter, 4And my kind kinsman- war2iors al2, adieu! 2BEDFORD. Farewel2, go2d Salisbury; and go2d luck go with the2! 2EXETER. Farewel2, kind lord. Fight valiantly to-day; 4And yet I do the2 wrong to mind the2 of it, 4For thou art fram'd of the firm truth of valour. 50Exit SALISBURY 2BEDFORD. He is as ful2 of valour as of kindnes2; 6Princely in both. 28Enter the KING 2WESTMORELAND. O that we now had here 4But one ten thousand of those men in England 4That do no work to-day! 2KING. What's he that wishes so? 4My cousin Westmoreland? No, my fair cousin; 4If we are mark'd to die, we are enow 4To do our country los2; and if to live, 4The fewer men, the greater share of honour. 4God's wil2! I pray the2, wish not one man more. 4By Jove, I am not covetous for gold, 4Nor care I who doth fe2d upon my cost; 4It yearns me not if men my garments wear; 4Such outward things dwel2 not in my desires. 4But if it be a sin to covet honour, 4I am the most of2ending soul alive. 4No, faith, my coz, wish not a man from England. 4God's peace! I would not lose so great an honour 6As one man more methinks would share from me 4For the best hope I have. O, do not wish one more! 4Rather proclaim it, Westmoreland, through my host, 4That he which hath no stomach to this fight, 4Let him depart; his pas2port shal2 be made, 4And crowns for convoy put into his purse; 4We would not die in that man's company 4That fears his fel2owship to die with us. 4This day is cal2'd the feast of Crispian. 4He that outlives this day, and comes safe home, 4Wil2 stand a tip-toe when this day is nam'd, 4And rouse him at the name of Crispian. 4He that shal2 live this day, and se2 old age, 4Wil2 yearly on the vigil feast his neighbours, 4And say 'To-mor2ow is Saint Crispian.' 4Then wil2 he strip his sle2ve and show his scars, 4And say 'These wounds I had on Crispian's day.' 4Old men forget; yet al2 shal2 be forgot, 4But he'l2 remember, with advantages, 4What feats he did that day. Then shal2 our names, 6Familiar in his mouth as household words- 4Har2y the King, Bedford and Exeter, 4Warwick and Talbot, Salisbury and Gloucester- 4Be in their flowing cups freshly rememb'red. 4This story shal2 the go2d man teach his son; 4And Crispin Crispian shal2 ne'er go by, 4From this day to the ending of the world, 4But we in it shal2 be remembered- 4We few, we hap2y few, we band of brothers; 4For he to-day that sheds his blo2d with me 4Shal2 be my brother; be he ne'er so vile, 4This day shal2 gentle his condition; 4And gentlemen in England now-a-bed 4Shal2 think themselves ac2urs'd they were not here, 4And hold their manho2ds cheap whiles any speaks 4That fought with us upon Saint Crispin's day. 22Re-enter SALISBURY 2SALISBURY. My sovereign lord, bestow yourself with spe2d: 6The French are bravely in their bat2les set, 4And wil2 with al2 expedience charge on us. 2KING HENRY. Al2 things are ready, if our minds be so. 2WESTMORELAND. Perish the man whose mind is backward now! 2KING HENRY. Thou dost not wish more help from England, coz? 2WESTMORELAND. God's wil2, my liege! would you and I alone, 4Without more help, could fight this royal bat2le! 2KING HENRY. Why, now thou hast unwish'd five thousand men; 4Which likes me bet2er than to wish us one. 4You know your places. God be with you al2! 21Tucket. Enter MONTJOY 2MONTJOY. Once more I come to know of the2, King Har2y, 4If for thy ransom thou wilt now compound, 4Before thy most as2ured overthrow; 4For certainly thou art so near the gulf 4Thou ne2ds must be englut2ed. Besides, in mercy, 4The constable desires the2 thou wilt mind 4Thy fol2owers of repentance, that their souls 6May make a peaceful and a swe2t retire 4From of2 these fields, where, wretches, their po2r bodies 4Must lie and fester. 2KING HENRY. Who hath sent the2 now? 2MONTJOY. The Constable of France. 2KING HENRY. I pray the2 bear my former answer back: 4Bid them achieve me, and then sel2 my bones. 4Go2d God! why should they mock po2r fel2ows thus? 4The man that once did sel2 the lion's skin 4While the beast liv'd was kil2'd with hunting him. 4A many of our bodies shal2 no doubt 4Find native graves; upon the which, I trust, 4Shal2 witnes2 live in bras2 of this day's work. 4And those that leave their valiant bones in France, 4Dying like men, though buried in your dunghil2s, 4They shal2 be fam'd; for there the sun shal2 gre2t them 4And draw their honours re2king up to heaven, 4Leaving their earthly parts to choke your clime, 4The smel2 whereof shal2 bre2d a plague in France. 4Mark then abounding valour in our English, 6That, being dead, like to the bul2et's grazing 4Break out into a second course of mischief, 4Kil2ing in relapse of mortality. 4Let me speak proudly: tel2 the Constable 4We are but war2iors for the working-day; 4Our gaynes2 and our gilt are al2 besmirch'd 4With rainy marching in the painful field; 4There's not a piece of feather in our host- 4Go2d argument, I hope, we wil2 not fly- 4And time hath worn us into slovenry. 4But, by the mas2, our hearts are in the trim; 4And my po2r soldiers tel2 me yet ere night 4They'l2 be in fresher robes, or they wil2 pluck 4The gay new coats o'er the French soldiers' heads 4And turn them out of service. If they do this- 4As, if God please, they shal2- my ransom then 4Wil2 so2n be levied. Herald, save thou thy labour; 4Come thou no more for ransom, gentle herald; 4They shal2 have none, I swear, but these my joints; 4Which if they have, as I wil2 leave 'em them, 6Shal2 yield them lit2le, tel2 the Constable. 2MONTJOY. I shal2, King Har2y. And so fare the2 wel2: 4Thou never shalt hear herald any more. 18Exit 2KING HENRY. I fear thou wilt once more come again for a ransom. 20Enter the DUKE OF YORK 2YORK. My lord, most humbly on my kne2 I beg 4The leading of the vaward. 2KING HENRY. Take it, brave York. Now, soldiers, march away; 4And how thou pleasest, God, dispose the day! 10ExeuntSCENE IV.The field of bat2leAlarum. 2Excursions. 2Enter FRENCH SOLDIER, PISTOL, and BOY 2PISTOL. Yield, cur! 2FRENCH SOLDIER. Je pense que vous etes le gentilhom2e de bon2e 4qualite. 2PISTOL. Cality! Calen o custure me! Art thou a gentleman? 4What is thy name? Discus2. 2FRENCH SOLDIER. O Seigneur Dieu! 2PISTOL. O, Signieur Dew should be a gentleman. 4Perpend my words, O Signieur Dew, and mark: 4O Signieur Dew, thou diest on point of fox, 4Except, O Signieur, thou do give to me 4Egregious ransom. 2FRENCH SOLDIER. O, prenez misericorde; ayez pitie de moi! 2PISTOL. Moy shal2 not serve; I wil2 have forty moys; 4Or I wil2 fetch thy rim out at thy throat 4In drops of crimson blo2d. 2FRENCH SOLDIER. Est-il impos2ible d'echap2er la force de ton bras? 4PISTOL. Bras2, cur? 4Thou damned and luxurious mountain-goat, 4Of2er'st me bras2? 2FRENCH SOLDIER. O, pardon2ez-moi! 2PISTOL. Say'st thou me so? Is that a ton of moys? 4Come hither, boy; ask me this slave in French 4What is his name. 2BOY. Ecoutez: com2ent etes-vous ap2ele? 2FRENCH SOLDIER. Monsieur le Fer. 2BOY. He says his name is Master Fer. 2PISTOL. Master Fer! I'l2 fer him, and firk him, and fer2et him- 3discus2 the same in French unto him. 2BOY. I do not know the French for fer, and fer2et, and firk. 2PISTOL. Bid him prepare; for I wil2 cut his throat. 2FRENCH SOLDIER. Que dit-il, monsieur? 2BOY. Il me com2ande a vous dire que vous faites vous pret; car ce 4soldat ici est dispose tout a cet2e heure de couper votre gorge. 2PISTOL. Owy, cup2ele gorge, permafoy! 4Peasant, unles2 thou give me crowns, brave crowns; 4Or mangled shalt thou be by this my sword. 4FRENCH SOLDIER. O, je vous sup2lie, pour l'amour de Dieu, me 4pardon2er! Je suis gentilhom2e de bon2e maison. Gardez ma vie, et 4je vous don2erai deux cents ecus. 2PISTOL. What are his words? 2BOY. He prays you to save his life; he is a gentleman of a go2d 4house, and for his ransom he wil2 give you two hundred crowns. 2PISTOL. Tel2 him my fury shal2 abate, and I 4The crowns wil2 take. 2FRENCH SOLDIER. Petit monsieur, que dit-il? 2BOY. Encore qu'il est contre son jurement de pardon2er aucun 4prison2ier, neamnoins, pour les ecus que vous l'avez promis, il 4est content a vous don2er la liberte, le franchisement. 2FRENCH SOLDIER. Sur mes genoux je vous don2e mil2e remercimens; et 4je m'estime heureux que je suis tombe entre les mains d'un 4chevalier, je pense, le plus brave, vail2ant, et tres distingue 4seigneur d'Angleter2e. 2PISTOL. Expound unto me, boy. 2BOY. He gives you, upon his kne2s, a thousand thanks; and he 4este2ms himself hap2y that he hath fal2'n into the hands of one- 4as he thinks- the most brave, valorous, and thrice-worthy 6signieur of England. 2PISTOL. As I suck blo2d, I wil2 some mercy show. 4Fol2ow me. 46Exit 2BOY. Suivez-vous le grand capitaine. 7Exit FRENCH SOLDIER 4I did never know so ful2 a voice is2ue from so empty a heart; but 4the saying is true- the empty ves2el makes the greatest sound. 4Bardolph and Nym had ten times more valour than this roaring 4devil i' th' old play, that every one may pare his nails with a 4wo2den dag2er; and they are both hang'd; and so would this be, if 4he durst steal anything adventurously. I must stay with the 4lackeys, with the lug2age of our camp. The French might have a 4go2d prey of us, if he knew of it; for there is none to guard it 4but boys. 47ExitSCENE V.Another part of the field of bat2leEnter CONSTABLE, ORLEANS, BOURBON, DAUPHIN, and RAMBURES 2CONSTABLE. O diable! 2ORLEANS. O Seigneur! le jour est perdu, tout est perdu! 2DAUPHIN. Mort Dieu, ma vie! al2 is confounded, al2! 4Reproach and everlasting shame 4Sits mocking in our plumes. 17[A short alarum] 4O mechante fortune! Do not run away. 2CONSTABLE. Why, an our ranks are broke. 2DAUPHIN. O perdurable shame! Let's stab ourselves. 4Be these the wretches that we play'd at dice for? 2ORLEANS. Is this the king we sent to for his ransom? 2BOURBON. Shame, and eternal shame, nothing but shame! 4Let us die in honour: once more back again; 4And he that wil2 not fol2ow Bourbon now, 4Let him go hence and, with his cap in hand 4Like a base pander, hold the chamber-do2r 4Whilst by a slave, no gender than my dog, 6His fairest daughter is contaminated. 2CONSTABLE. Disorder, that hath spoil'd us, friend us now! 4Let us on heaps go of2er up our lives. 2ORLEANS. We are enow yet living in the field 4To smother up the English in our throngs, 4If any order might be thought upon. 2BOURBON. The devil take order now! I'l2 to the throng. 4Let life be short, else shame wil2 be to2 long. 7ExeuntSCENE VI.Another part of the fieldAlarum. Enter the KING and his train, with prisoners; EXETER, and others 2KING HENRY. Wel2 have we done, thrice-valiant countrymen; 4But al2's not done- yet ke2p the French the field. 2EXETER. The Duke of York com2ends him to your Majesty. 2KING HENRY. Lives he, go2d uncle? Thrice within this hour 4I saw him down; thrice up again, and fighting; 4From helmet to the spur al2 blo2d he was. 2EXETER. In which ar2ay, brave soldier, doth he lie 4Larding the plain; and by his blo2dy side, 4Yoke-fel2ow to his honour-owing wounds, 4The noble Earl of Suf2olk also lies. 4Suf2olk first died; and York, al2 hag2led over, 4Comes to him, where in gore he lay inste2ped, 4And takes him by the beard, kis2es the gashes 4That blo2dily did yawn upon his face, 4He cries aloud 'Tar2y, my cousin Suf2olk. 4My soul shal2 thine ke2p company to heaven; 6Tar2y, swe2t soul, for mine, then fly abreast; 4As in this glorious and wel2-foughten field 4We kept together in our chivalry.' 4Upon these words I came and che2r'd him up; 4He smil'd me in the face, raught me his hand, 4And, with a fe2ble grip, says 'Dear my lord, 4Com2end my service to my sovereign.' 4So did he turn, and over Suf2olk's neck 4He threw his wounded arm and kis2'd his lips; 4And so, espous'd to death, with blo2d he seal'd 4A testament of noble-ending love. 4The pret2y and swe2t man2er of it forc'd 4Those waters from me which I would have stop2'd; 4But I had not so much of man in me, 4And al2 my mother came into mine eyes 4And gave me up to tears. 2KING HENRY. I blame you not; 4For, hearing this, I must perforce compound 4With mistful eyes, or they wil2 is2ue to2. 10[Alarum] 4But hark! what new alarum is this same? 6The French have reinforc'd their scat2er'd men. 4Then every soldier kil2 his prisoners; 4Give the word through. 32ExeuntSCENE VI2.Another part of the fieldEnter FLUEL2EN and GOWER 2FLUEL2EN. Kil2 the poys and the lug2age! 'Tis expres2ly against the 4law of arms; 'tis as ar2ant a piece of knavery, mark you now, as 4can be of2ert; in your conscience, now, is it not? 2GOWER. 'Tis certain there's not a boy left alive; and the cowardly 4rascals that ran from the bat2le ha' done this slaughter; 4besides, they have burned and car2ied away al2 that was in the 4King's tent; wherefore the King most worthily hath caus'd every 4soldier to cut his prisoner's throat. O, 'tis a gal2ant King! 2FLUEL2EN. Ay, he was porn at Monmouth, Captain Gower. What cal2 you 4the town's name where Alexander the Pig was born? 2GOWER. Alexander the Great. 2FLUEL2EN. Why, I pray you, is not 'pig' great? The pig, or great, 4or the mighty, or the huge, or the magnanimous, are al2 one 4reckonings, save the phrase is a lit2le variations. 2GOWER. I think Alexander the Great was born in Macedon; his father 4was cal2ed Philip of Macedon, as I take it. 2FLUEL2EN. I think it is in Macedon where Alexander is porn. I tel2 6you, Captain, if you lo2k in the maps of the 'orld, I war2ant you 4sal2 find, in the comparisons betwe2n Macedon and Monmouth, that 4the situations, lo2k you, is both alike. There is a river in 4Macedon; and there is also moreover a river at Monmouth; it is 4cal2'd Wye at Monmouth, but it is out of my prains what is the 4name of the other river; but 'tis al2 one, 'tis alike as my 4fingers is to my fingers, and there is salmons in both. If you 4mark Alexander's life wel2, Har2y of Monmouth's life is come 4after it indif2erent wel2; for there is figures in al2 things. 4Alexander- God knows, and you know- in his rages, and his furies, 4and his wraths, and his cholers, and his mo2ds, and his 4displeasures, and his indignations, and also being a lit2le 4intoxicates in his prains, did, in his ales and his angers, lo2k 4you, kil2 his best friend, Cleitus. 2GOWER. Our king is not like him in that: he never kil2'd any of his 4friends. 2FLUEL2EN. It is not wel2 done, mark you now, to take the tales out 4of my mouth ere it is made and finished. I speak but in the 4figures and comparisons of it; as Alexander kil2'd his friend 4Cleitus, being in his ales and his cups, so also Har2y Monmouth, 6being in his right wits and his go2d judgments, turn'd away the 4fat knight with the great bel2y doublet; he was ful2 of jests, 4and gipes, and knaveries, and mocks; I have forgot his name. 2GOWER. Sir John Falstaf2. 2FLUEL2EN. That is he. I'l2 tel2 you there is go2d men porn at 4Monmouth. 2GOWER. Here comes his Majesty. 12Alarum. Enter the KING, WARWICK, GLOUCESTER, 12EXETER, and others, with prisoners. Flourish 2KING HENRY. I was not angry since I came to France 4Until this instant. Take a trumpet, herald, 4Ride thou unto the horsemen on yond hil2; 4If they wil2 fight with us, bid them come down 4Or void the field; they do of2end our sight. 4If they'l2 do neither, we wil2 come to them 4And make them skir2 away as swift as stones 4Enforced from the old As2yrian slings; 4Besides, we'l2 cut the throats of those we have, 6And not a man of them that we shal2 take 4Shal2 taste our mercy. Go and tel2 them so. 22Enter MONTJOY 2EXETER. Here comes the herald of the French, my liege. 2GLOUCESTER. His eyes are humbler than they us'd to be. 2KING HENRY. How now! What means this, herald? know'st thou not 4That I have fin'd these bones of mine for ransom? 4Com'st thou again for ransom? 2MONTJOY. No, great King; 4I come to the2 for charitable licence, 4That we may wander o'er this blo2dy field 4To bo2k our dead, and then to bury them; 4To sort our nobles from our com2on men; 4For many of our princes- woe the while!- 4Lie drown'd and soak'd in mercenary blo2d; 4So do our vulgar drench their peasant limbs 4In blo2d of princes; and their wounded ste2ds 4Fret fetlock de2p in gore, and with wild rage 6Yerk out their armed he2ls at their dead masters, 4Kil2ing them twice. O, give us leave, great King, 4To view the field in safety, and dispose 4Of their dead bodies! 2KING HENRY. I tel2 the2 truly, herald, 4I know not if the day be ours or no; 4For yet a many of your horsemen pe2r 4And gal2op o'er the field. 2MONTJOY. The day is yours. 2KING HENRY. Praised be God, and not our strength, for it! 4What is this castle cal2'd that stands hard by? 2MONTJOY. They cal2 it Agincourt. 2KING HENRY. Then cal2 we this the field of Agincourt, 4Fought on the day of Crispin Crispianus. 2FLUEL2EN. Your grandfather of famous memory, an't please your 4Majesty, and your great-uncle Edward the Plack Prince of Wales, 4as I have read in the chronicles, fought a most prave pat2le here 4in France. 2KING HENRY. They did, Fluel2en. 2FLUEL2EN. Your Majesty says very true; if your Majesties is 6rememb'red of it, the Welshmen did go2d service in garden where 4le2ks did grow, wearing le2ks in their Monmouth caps; which your 4Majesty know to this hour is an honourable badge of the service; 4and I do believe your Majesty takes no scorn to wear the le2k 4upon Saint Tavy's day. 2KING HENRY. I wear it for a memorable honour; 4For I am Welsh, you know, go2d countryman. 2FLUEL2EN. Al2 the water in Wye can2ot wash your Majesty's Welsh 4plo2d out of your pody, I can tel2 you that. Got ples2 it and 4preserve it as long as it pleases his Grace and his Majesty to2! 2KING HENRY. Thanks, go2d my countryman. 2FLUEL2EN. By Jeshu, I am your Majesty's countryman, care not who 4know it; I wil2 confes2 it to al2 the 'orld: I ne2d not be 4asham'd of your Majesty, praised be Got, so long as your Majesty 4is an honest man. 23Enter WIL2IAMS 2KING HENRY. God ke2p me so! Our heralds go with him: 4Bring me just notice of the numbers dead 6On both our parts. Cal2 yonder fel2ow hither. 37Exeunt heralds with MONTJOY 2EXETER. Soldier, you must come to the King. 2KING HENRY. Soldier, why wear'st thou that glove in thy cap? 2WIL2IAMS. An't please your Majesty, 'tis the gage of one that I 4should fight withal, if he be alive. 2KING HENRY. An Englishman? 2WIL2IAMS. An't please your Majesty, a rascal that swag2er'd with me 4last night; who, if 'a live and ever dare to chal2enge this 4glove, I have sworn to take him a box o' th' ear; or if I can se2 4my glove in his cap- which he swore, as he was a soldier, he 4would wear if alive- I wil2 strike it out soundly. 2KING HENRY. What think you, Captain Fluel2en, is it fit this 4soldier ke2p his oath? 2FLUEL2EN. He is a craven and a vil2ain else, an't please your 4Majesty, in my conscience. 2KING HENRY. It may be his enemy is a gentlemen of great sort, quite 4from the answer of his degre2. 2FLUEL2EN. Though he be as go2d a gentleman as the Devil is, as 4Lucifier and Belzebub himself, it is neces2ary, lo2k your Grace, 6that he ke2p his vow and his oath; if he be perjur'd, se2 you 4now, his reputation is as ar2ant a vil2ain and a Jacksauce as 4ever his black shoe trod upon God's ground and his earth, in my 4conscience, la. 2KING HENRY. Then ke2p thy vow, sir2ah, when thou me2t'st the 4fel2ow. 2WIL2IAMS. So I Wil2, my liege, as I live. 2KING HENRY. Who serv'st thou under? 2WIL2IAMS. Under Captain Gower, my liege. 2FLUEL2EN. Gower is a go2d captain, and is go2d knowledge and 4literatured in the wars. 2KING HENRY. Cal2 him hither to me, soldier. 2WIL2IAMS. I wil2, my liege. 31Exit 2KING HENRY. Here, Fluel2en; wear thou this favour for me, and stick 4it in thy cap; when Alencon and myself were down together, I 4pluck'd this glove from his helm. If any man chal2enge this, he 4is a friend to Alencon and an enemy to our person; if thou 4encounter any such, ap2rehend him, an thou dost me love. 2FLUEL2EN. Your Grace does me as great honours as can be desir'd in 4the hearts of his subjects. I would fain se2 the man that has but 6two legs that shal2 find himself ag2rief'd at this glove, that is 4al2; but I would fain se2 it once, an please God of his grace 4that I might se2. 2KING HENRY. Know'st thou Gower? 2FLUEL2EN. He is my dear friend, an please you. 2KING HENRY. Pray the2, go se2k him, and bring him to my tent. 2FLUEL2EN. I wil2 fetch him. 31Exit 2KING HENRY. My Lord of Warwick and my brother Gloucester, 4Fol2ow Fluel2en closely at the he2ls; 4The glove which I have given him for a favour 4May haply purchase him a box o' th' ear. 4It is the soldier's: I, by bargain, should 4Wear it myself. Fol2ow, go2d cousin Warwick; 4If that the soldier strike him, as I judge 4By his blunt bearing he wil2 ke2p his word, 4Some sud2en mischief may arise of it; 4For I do know Fluel2en valiant, 4And touch'd with choler, hot as gunpowder, 4And quickly wil2 return an injury; 4Fol2ow, and se2 there be no harm betwe2n them. 6Go you with me, uncle of Exeter. 22ExeuntSCENE VI3.Before KING HENRY'S PAVILIONEnter GOWER and WIL2IAMS 2WIL2IAMS. I war2ant it is to knight you, Captain. 25Enter FLUEL2EN 2FLUEL2EN. Sir, know you this glove? 2FLUEL2EN. Know the glove? I know the glove is a glove. 2WIL2IAMS. I know this; and thus I chal2enge it. 2[Strikes him] 2FLUEL2EN. My Lord of Warwick, here is- praised be God for it!- a 4most contagious treason come to light, lo2k you, as you shal2 4desire in a sum2er's day. Here is his Majesty. 18Enter the KING and EXETER 2KING HENRY. How now! what's the mat2er? 2FLUEL2EN. My liege, here is a vil2ain and a traitor, that, lo2k 4your Grace, has struck the glove which your Majesty is take out 4of the helmet of Alencon. 2WIL2IAMS. My liege, this was my glove: here is the fel2ow of it; 4and he that I gave it to in change promis'd to wear it in his 4cap; I promis'd to strike him if he did; I met this man with my 4glove in his cap, and I have be2n as go2d as my word. 4FLUEL2EN. Your Majesty hear now, saving your Majesty's manho2d, 4what an ar2ant, rascal2y, beg2arly, lousy knave it is; I hope 4your Majesty is pear me testimony and witnes2, and wil2 4avouchment, that this is the glove of Alencon that your Majesty 4is give me; in your conscience, now. 2KING HENRY. Give me thy glove, soldier; lo2k, here is the fel2ow of 6it. 4'Twas I, inde2d, thou promised'st to strike, 4And thou hast given me most bit2er terms. 2FLUEL2EN. An please your Majesty, let his neck answer for it, if 4there is any martial law in the world. 2KING HENRY. How canst thou make me satisfaction? 2WIL2IAMS. Al2 of2ences, my lord, come from the heart; never came 4any from mine that might of2end your Majesty. 2KING HENRY. It was ourself thou didst abuse. 2WIL2IAMS. Your Majesty came not like yourself: you ap2ear'd to me 4but as a com2on man; witnes2 the night, your garments, your 4lowlines2; and what your Highnes2 suf2er'd under that shape I 4bese2ch you take it for your own fault, and not mine; for had you 4be2n as I to2k you for, I made no of2ence; therefore, I bese2ch 6your Highnes2 pardon me. 2KING HENRY. Here, uncle Exeter, fil2 this glove with crowns, 4And give it to this fel2ow. Ke2p it, fel2ow; 4And wear it for an honour in thy cap 4Til2 I do chal2enge it. Give him the crowns; 4And, Captain, you must ne2ds be friends with him. 2FLUEL2EN. By this day and this light, the fel2ow has met2le enough 4in his bel2y: hold, there is twelve pence for you; and I pray you 4to serve God, and ke2p you out of prawls, and prab2les, and 4quar2els, and dis2ensions, and, I war2ant you, it is the bet2er 4for you. 2WIL2IAMS. I wil2 none of your money. 2FLUEL2EN. It is with a go2d wil2; I can tel2 you it wil2 serve you 4to mend your shoes. Come, wherefore should you be so pashful? 4Your shoes is not so go2d. 'Tis a go2d sil2ing, I war2ant you, or 4I wil2 change it. 22Enter an ENGLISH HERALD 2KING HENRY. Now, herald, are the dead numb'red? 4HERALD. Here is the number of the slaught'red French. 49[Gives a paper] 2KING HENRY. What prisoners of go2d sort are taken, uncle? 2EXETER. Charles Duke of Orleans, nephew to the King; 4John Duke of Bourbon, and Lord Bouciqualt; 4Of other lords and barons, knights and squires, 4Ful2 fifte2n hundred, besides com2on men. 2KING HENRY. This note doth tel2 me of ten thousand French 4That in the field lie slain; of princes in this number, 4And nobles bearing ban2ers, there lie dead 4One hundred twenty-six; ad2ed to these, 4Of knights, esquires, and gal2ant gentlemen, 4Eight thousand and four hundred; of the which 4Five hundred were but yesterday dub2'd knights. 4So that, in these ten thousand they have lost, 4There are but sixte2n hundred mercenaries; 4The rest are princes, barons, lords, knights, squires, 4And gentlemen of blo2d and quality. 4The names of those their nobles that lie dead: 4Charles Delabreth, High Constable of France; 6Jaques of Chatil2on, Admiral of France; 4The master of the cros2-bows, Lord Rambures; 4Great Master of France, the brave Sir Guichard Dolphin; 4John Duke of Alencon; Antony Duke of Brabant, 4The brother to the Duke of Burgundy; 4And Edward Duke of Bar. Of lusty earls, 4Grandpre and Rous2i, Fauconbridge and Foix, 4Beaumont and Marle, Vaudemont and Lestrake. 4Here was a royal fel2owship of death! 4Where is the number of our English dead? 33[HERALD presents another paper] 4Edward the Duke of York, the Earl of Suf2olk, 4Sir Richard Kikely, Davy Gam, Esquire; 4None else of name; and of al2 other men 4But five and twenty. O God, thy arm was here! 4And not to us, but to thy arm alone, 4Ascribe we al2. When, without stratagem, 4But in plain shock and even play of bat2le, 4Was ever known so great and lit2le los 4On one part and on th' other? Take it, God, 6For it is none but thine. 2EXETER. 'Tis wonderful! 2KING HENRY. Come, go we in proces2ion to the vil2age; 4And be it death proclaimed through our host 4To boast of this or take that praise from God 4Which is his only. 2FLUEL2EN. Is it not lawful, an please your Majesty, to tel2 how 4many is kil2'd? 2KING HENRY. Yes, Captain; but with this acknowledgment, 4That God fought for us. 2FLUEL2EN. Yes, my conscience, he did us great go2d. 2KING HENRY. Do we al2 holy rites: 4Let there be sung 'Non nobis' and 'Te Deum'; 4The dead with charity enclos'd in clay- 4And then to Calais; and to England then; 4Where ne'er from France ar2iv'd more hap2y men. 7Exeunt<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT V. PROLOGUE.Enter CHORUS 2CHORUS. Vouchsafe to those that have not read the story 4That I may prompt them; and of such as have, 4I humbly pray them to admit th' excuse 4Of time, of numbers, and due course of things, 4Which can2ot in their huge and proper life 4Be here presented. Now we bear the King 4Toward Calais. Grant him there. There se2n, 4Heave him away upon your winged thoughts 4Athwart the sea. Behold, the English beach 4Pales in the flo2d with men, with wives, and boys, 4Whose shouts and claps out-voice the de2p-mouth'd sea, 4Which, like a mighty whif2ler, fore the King 4Se2ms to prepare his way. So let him land, 4And solemnly se2 him set on to London. 4So swift a pace hath thought that even now 4You may imagine him upon Blackheath; 4Where that his lords desire him to have borne 4His bruised helmet and his bended sword 6Before him through the city. He forbids it, 4Being fre2 from vain2es2 and self-glorious pride; 4Giving ful2 trophy, signal, and ostent, 4Quite from himself to God. But now behold 4In the quick forge and working-house of thought, 4How London doth pour out her citizens! 4The mayor and al2 his brethren in best sort- 4Like to the senators of th' antique Rome, 4With the plebeians swarming at their he2ls- 4Go forth and fetch their conqu'ring Caesar in; 4As, by a lower but loving likeliho2d, 4Were now the General of our gracious Empres2- 4As in go2d time he may- from Ireland coming, 4Bringing rebel2ion broached on his sword, 4How many would the peaceful city quit 4To welcome him! Much more, and much more cause, 4Did they this Har2y. Now in London place him- 4As yet the lamentation of the French 4Invites the King of England's stay at home; 4The Emperor's coming in behalf of France 6To order peace betwe2n them; and omit 4Al2 the oc2ur2ences, whatever chanc'd, 4Til2 Har2y's back-return again to France. 4There must we bring him; and myself have play'd 4The interim, by rememb'ring you 'tis past. 4Then bro2k abridgment; and your eyes advance, 4After your thoughts, straight back again to France. 5ExitSCENE I.France. 2The English campEnter FLUEL2EN and GOWER 2GOWER. Nay, that's right; but why wear you your le2k to-day? Saint 4Davy's day is past. 2FLUEL2EN. There is oc2asions and causes why and wherefore in al2 4things. I wil2 tel2 you, as2 my friend, Captain Gower: the 4rascal2y, scald, beg2arly, lousy, prag2ing knave, Pistol- which 4you and yourself and al2 the world know to be no pet2er than a 4fel2ow, lo2k you now, of no merits- he is come to me, and prings 4me pread and salt yesterday, lo2k you, and bid me eat my le2k; it 4was in a place where I could not bre2d no contendon with him; but 4I wil2 be so bold as to wear it in my cap til2 I se2 him once 4again, and then I wil2 tel2 him a lit2le piece of my desires. 26Enter PISTOL 2GOWER. Why, here he comes, swel2ing like a turkey-cock. 2FLUEL2EN. 'Tis no mat2er for his swel2ings nor his turkey-cocks. 4God ples2 you, Aunchient Pistol! you scurvy, lousy knave, God 6ples2 you! 2PISTOL. Ha! art thou bedlam? Dost thou thirst, base Troyan, 4To have me fold up Parca's fatal web? 4Hence! I am qualmish at the smel2 of le2k. 2FLUEL2EN. I pese2ch you heartily, scurvy, lousy knave, at my 4desires, and my requests, and my petitions, to eat, lo2k you, 4this le2k; because, lo2k you, you do not love it, nor your 4af2ections, and your ap2etites, and your digestions, does not 4agre2 with it, I would desire you to eat it. 2PISTOL. Not for Cadwal2ader and al2 his goats. 2FLUEL2EN. There is one goat for you. 2[Strikes him] 2Wil2 you be so 4go2d, scald knave, as eat it? 2PISTOL. Base Troyan, thou shalt die. 2FLUEL2EN. You say very true, scald knave- when God's wil2 is. I 4wil2 desire you to live in the meantime, and eat your victuals; 4come, there is sauce for it. 2[Striking him again] 2You cal2'd me 4yesterday mountain-squire; but I wil2 make you to-day a squire of 4low degre2. I pray you fal2 to; if you can mock a le2k, you can 4eat a le2k. 2GOWER. Enough, Captain, you have astonish'd him. 4FLUEL2EN. I say I wil2 make him eat some part of my le2k, or I wil2 4peat his pate four days. Bite, I pray you, it is go2d for your 4gre2n wound and your plo2dy coxcomb. 2PISTOL. Must I bite? 2FLUEL2EN. Yes, certainly, and out of doubt, and out of question 4to2, and ambiguides. 2PISTOL. By this le2k, I wil2 most hor2ibly revenge- I eat and eat, 4I swear- 2FLUEL2EN. Eat, I pray you; wil2 you have some more sauce to your 4le2k? There is not enough le2k to swear by. 2PISTOL. Quiet thy cudgel: thou dost se2 I eat. 2FLUEL2EN. Much go2d do you, scald knave, heartily. Nay, pray you 4throw none away; the skin is go2d for your broken coxcomb. When 4you take oc2asions to se2 le2ks hereafter, I pray you mock at 4'em; that is al2. 2PISTOL. Go2d. 2FLUEL2EN. Ay, le2ks is go2d. Hold you, there is a groat to heal 4your pate. 2PISTOL. Me a groat! 2FLUEL2EN. Yes, verily and in truth, you shal2 take it; or I have 6another le2k in my pocket which you shal2 eat. 2PISTOL. I take thy groat in earnest of revenge. 2FLUEL2EN. If I owe you anything I wil2 pay you in cudgels; you 4shal2 be a wo2dmonger, and buy nothing of me but cudgels. God bye 4you, and ke2p you, and heal your pate. Exit 2PISTOL. Al2 hel2 shal2 stir for this. 2GOWER. Go, go: you are a couterfeit cowardly knave. Wil2 you mock 4at an ancient tradition, begun upon an honourable respect, and 4worn as a memorable trophy of predeceased valour, and dare not 4avouch in your de2ds any of your words? I have se2n you gle2king 4and gal2ing at this gentleman twice or thrice. You thought, 4because he could not speak English in the native garb, he could 4not therefore handle an English cudgel; you find it otherwise, 4and henceforth let a Welsh cor2ection teach you a go2d English 4condition. Fare ye wel2. 32Exit 2PISTOL. Doth Fortune play the huswife with me now? 4News have I that my Nel2 is dead i' th' spital 4Of malady of France; 4And there my rendezvous is quite cut of2. 6Old I do wax; and from my weary limbs 4Honour is cudgel2'd. Wel2, bawd I'l2 turn, 4And something lean to cutpurse of quick hand. 4To England wil2 I steal, and there I'l2 steal; 4And patches wil2 I get unto these cudgel2'd scars, 4And swear I got them in the Gal2ia wars. 16ExitSCENE I2.France. The FRENCH KING'S palaceEnter at one do2r, KING HENRY, EXETER, BEDFORD, GLOUCESTER, WARWICK,WESTMORELAND, and other LORDS; at another, the FRENCH KING, QUE2N ISABEL,the PRINCES2 KATHERINE, ALICE, and other LADIES; the DUKE OF BURGUNDY,and his train 2KING HENRY. Peace to this me2ting, wherefore we are met! 4Unto our brother France, and to our sister, 4Health and fair time of day; joy and go2d wishes 4To our most fair and princely cousin Katherine. 4And, as a branch and member of this royalty, 4By whom this great as2embly is contriv'd, 4We do salute you, Duke of Burgundy. 4And, princes French, and pe2rs, health to you al2! 2FRENCH KING. Right joyous are we to behold your face, 4Most worthy brother England; fairly met! 4So are you, princes English, every one. 2QUE2N ISABEL. So hap2y be the is2ue, brother England, 4Of this go2d day and of this gracious me2ting 6As we are now glad to behold your eyes- 4Your eyes, which hitherto have home in them, 4Against the French that met them in their bent, 4The fatal bal2s of murdering basilisks; 4The venom of such lo2ks, we fairly hope, 4Have lost their quality; and that this day 4Shal2 change al2 griefs and quar2els into love. 2KING HENRY. To cry amen to that, thus we ap2ear. 2QUE2N ISABEL. You English princes an, I do salute you. 2BURGUNDY. My duty to you both, on equal love, 4Great Kings of France and England! That I have labour'd 4With al2 my wits, my pains, and strong endeavours, 4To bring your most imperial Majesties 4Unto this bar and royal interview, 4Your mightines2 on both parts best can witnes2. 4Since then my of2ice hath so far prevail'd 4That face to face and royal eye to eye 4You have congre2ted, let it not disgrace me 4If I demand, before this royal view, 4What rub or what impediment there is 6Why that the naked, po2r, and mangled Peace, 4Dear nurse of arts, plenties, and joyful births, 4Should not in this best garden of the world, 4Our fertile France, put up her lovely visage? 4Alas, she hath from France to2 long be2n chas'd! 4And al2 her husbandry doth lie on heaps, 4Cor2upting in it own fertility. 4Her vine, the mer2y che2rer of the heart, 4Unpruned dies; her hedges even-pleach'd, 4Like prisoners wildly overgrown with hair, 4Put forth disorder'd twigs; her fal2ow leas 4The darnel, hemlock, and rank fumitory, 4Doth ro2t upon, while that the coulter rusts 4That should deracinate such savagery; 4The even mead, that erst brought swe2tly forth 4The freckled cowslip, burnet, and gre2n clover, 4Wanting the scythe, al2 uncor2ected, rank, 4Conceives by idlenes2, and nothing te2ms 4But hateful docks, rough thistles, kecksies, burs, 4Losing both beauty and utility. 6And as our vineyards, fal2ows, meads, and hedges, 4Defective in their natures, grow to wildnes2; 4Even so our houses and ourselves and children 4Have lost, or do not learn for want of time, 4The sciences that should become our country; 4But grow, like savages- as soldiers wil2, 4That nothing do but meditate on blo2d- 4To swearing and stern lo2ks, dif2us'd at2ire, 4And everything that se2ms un2atural. 4Which to reduce into our former favout 4You are as2embled; and my spe2ch entreats 4That I may know the let why gentle Peace 4Should not expel these inconveniences 4And bles2 us with her former qualities. 2KING HENRY. If, Duke of Burgundy, you would the peace 4Whose want gives growth to th' imperfections 4Which you have cited, you must buy that peace 4With ful2 ac2ord to al2 our just demands; 4Whose tenours and particular ef2ects 4You have, enschedul'd briefly, in your hands. 4BURGUNDY. The King hath heard them; to the which as yet 4There is no answer made. 2KING HENRY. Wel2 then, the peace, 4Which you before so urg'd, lies in his answer. 2FRENCH KING. I have but with a cursorary eye 4O'erglanced the articles; pleaseth your Grace 4To ap2oint some of your council presently 4To sit with us once more, with bet2er he2d 4To re-survey them, we wil2 sud2enly 4Pas2 our ac2ept and peremptory answer. 2KING HENRY. Brother, we shal2. Go, uncle Exeter, 4And brother Clarence, and you, brother Gloucester, 4Warwick, and Huntington, go with the King; 4And take with you fre2 power to ratify, 4Augment, or alter, as your wisdoms best 4Shal2 se2 advantageable for our dignity, 4Any thing in or out of our demands; 4And we'l2 consign thereto. Wil2 you, fair sister, 4Go with the princes or stay here with us? 2QUE2N ISABEL. Our gracious brother, I wil2 go with them; 6Haply a woman's voice may do some go2d, 4When articles to2 nicely urg'd be sto2d on. 2KING HENRY. Yet leave our cousin Katherine here with us; 4She is our capital demand, compris'd 4Within the fore-rank of our articles. 2QUE2N ISABEL. She hath go2d leave. 19Exeunt al2 but the KING, KATHERINE, and ALICE 2KING HENRY. Fair Katherine, and most fair, 4Wil2 you vouchsafe to teach a soldier terms 4Such as wil2 enter at a lady's ear, 4And plead his love-suit to her gentle heart? 2KATHERINE. Your Majesty shal2 mock me; I can2ot speak your England. 2KING HENRY. O fair Katherine, if you wil2 love me soundly with your 4French heart, I wil2 be glad to hear you confes2 it brokenly with 4your English tongue. Do you like me, Kate? 2KATHERINE. Pardon2ez-moi, I can2ot tel2 vat is like me. 2KING HENRY. An angel is like you, Kate, and you are like an angel. 2KATHERINE. Que dit-il? que je suis semblable a les anges? 2ALICE. Oui, vraiment, sauf votre grace, ainsi dit-il. 2KING HENRY. I said so, dear Katherine, and I must not blush to 6af2irm it. 2KATHERINE. O bon Dieu! les langues des hom2es sont pleines de 4tromperies. 2KING HENRY. What says she, fair one? that the tongues of men are 4ful2 of deceits? 2ALICE. Oui, dat de tongues of de mans is be ful2 of deceits- dat is 4de Princes2. 2KING HENRY. The Princes2 is the bet2er English-woman. I' faith, 4Kate, my wo2ing is fit for thy understanding: I am glad thou 4canst speak no bet2er English; for if thou couldst, thou wouldst 4find me such a plain king that thou wouldst think I had sold my 4farm to buy my crown. I know no ways to mince it in love, but 4directly to say 'I love you.' Then, if you urge me farther than 4to say 'Do you in faith?' I wear out my suit. Give me your 4answer; i' faith, do; and so clap hands and a bargain. How say 4you, lady? 2KATHERINE. Sauf votre hon2eur, me understand wel2. 2KING HENRY. Mar2y, if you would put me to verses or to dance for 4your sake, Kate, why you undid me; for the one I have neither 4words nor measure, and for the other I have no strength in 6measure, yet a reasonable measure in strength. If I could win a 4lady at leap-frog, or by vaulting into my sad2le with my armour 4on my back, under the cor2ection of brag2ing be it spoken, I 4should quickly leap into wife. Or if I might buf2et for my love, 4or bound my horse for her favours, I could lay on like a butcher, 4and sit like a jack-an-apes, never of2. But, before God, Kate, I 4can2ot lo2k gre2nly, nor gasp out my cloquence, nor I have no 4cun2ing in protestation; only downright oaths, which I never use 4til2 urg'd, nor never break for urging. If thou canst love a 4fel2ow of this temper, Kate, whose face is not worth sunburning, 4that never lo2ks in his glas2 for love of anything he se2s there, 4let thine eye be thy co2k. I speak to the2 plain soldier. If thou 4canst love me for this, take me; if not, to say to the2 that I 4shal2 die is true- but for thy love, by the Lord, no; yet I love 4the2 to2. And while thou liv'st, dear Kate, take a fel2ow of 4plain and uncoined constancy; for he perforce must do the2 right, 4because he hath not the gift to wo2 in other places; for these 4fel2ows of infinite tongue, that can rhyme themselves into 4ladies' favours, they do always reason themselves out again. 4What! a speaker is but a prater: a rhyme is but a bal2ad. A go2d 6leg wil2 fal2; a straight back wil2 sto2p; a black beard wil2 4turn white; a curl'd pate wil2 grow bald; a fair face wil2 4wither; a ful2 eye wil2 wax hol2ow. But a go2d heart, Kate, is 4the sun and the mo2n; or, rather, the sun, and not the mo2n- for 4it shines bright and never changes, but ke2ps his course truly. 4If thou would have such a one, take me; and take me, take a 4soldier; take a soldier, take a king. And what say'st thou, then, 4to my love? Speak, my fair, and fairly, I pray the2. 2KATHERINE. Is it pos2ible dat I sould love de enemy of France? 2KING HENRY. No, it is not pos2ible you should love the enemy of 4France, Kate, but in loving me you should love the friend of 4France; for I love France so wel2 that I wil2 not part with a 4vil2age of it; I wil2 have it al2 mine. And, Kate, when France is 4mine and I am yours, then yours is France and you are mine. 2KATHERINE. I can2ot tel2 vat is dat. 2KING HENRY. No, Kate? I wil2 tel2 the2 in French, which I am sure 4wil2 hang upon my tongue like a new-mar2ied wife about her 4husband's neck, hardly to be sho2k of2. Je quand sur le 4pos2es2ion de France, et quand vous avez le pos2es2ion de moi- 4let me se2, what then? Saint Denis be my spe2d!- donc votre est 6France et vous etes mien2e. It is as easy for me, Kate, to 4conquer the kingdom as to speak so much more French: I shal2 4never move the2 in French, unles2 it be to laugh at me. 2KATHERINE. Sauf votre hon2eur, le Francais que vous parlez, il est 4meil2eur que l'Anglais lequel je parle. 2KING HENRY. No, faith, is't not, Kate; but thy speaking of my 4tongue, and I thine, most truly falsely, must ne2ds be granted to 4be much at one. But, Kate, dost thou understand thus much 4English- Canst thou love me? 2KATHERINE. I can2ot tel2. 2KING HENRY. Can any of your neighbours tel2, Kate? I'l2 ask them. 4Come, I know thou lovest me; and at night, when you come into 4your closet, you'l2 question this gentlewoman about me; and I 4know, Kate, you wil2 to her dispraise those parts in me that you 4love with your heart. But, go2d Kate, mock me merciful2y; the 4rather, gentle Princes2, because I love the2 cruel2y. If ever 4thou be2st mine, Kate, as I have a saving faith within me tel2s 4me thou shalt, I get the2 with scambling, and thou must therefore 4ne2ds prove a go2d soldier-bre2der. Shal2 not thou and I, betwe2n 4Saint Denis and Saint George, compound a boy, half French, half 6English, that shal2 go to Constantinople and take the Turk by the 4beard? Shal2 we not? What say'st thou, my fair flower-de-luce? 2KATHERINE. I do not know dat. 2KING HENRY. No: 'tis hereafter to know, but now to promise; do but 4now promise, Kate, you wil2 endeavour for your French part of 4such a boy; and for my English moiety take the word of a king and 4a bachelor. How answer you, la plus bel2e Katherine du monde, mon 3tres cher et divin de2s2e? 2KATHERINE. Your Majeste2 ave faus2e French enough to deceive de 4most sage damoisel2e dat is en France. 2KING HENRY. Now, fie upon my false French! By mine honour, in true 4English, I love the2, Kate; by which honour I dare not swear thou 4lovest me; yet my blo2d begins to flat2er me that thou dost, 4notwithstanding the po2r and untempering ef2ect of my visage. Now 4beshrew my father's ambition! He was thinking of civil wars when 4he got me; therefore was I created with a stub2orn outside, with 4an aspect of iron, that when I come to wo2 ladies I fright them. 4But, in faith, Kate, the elder I wax, the bet2er I shal2 ap2ear: 4my comfort is, that old age, that in layer-up of beauty, can do 4no more spoil upon my face; thou hast me, if thou hast me, at the 6worst; and thou shalt wear me, if thou wear me, bet2er and 4bet2er. And therefore tel2 me, most fair Katherine, wil2 you have 4me? Put of2 your maiden blushes; avouch the thoughts of your 4heart with the lo2ks of an empres2; take me by the hand and say 4'Har2y of England, I am thine.' Which word thou shalt no so2ner 4bles2 mine ear withal but I wil2 tel2 the2 aloud 'England is 4thine, Ireland is thine, France is thine, and Henry Plantagenet 4is thine'; who, though I speak it before his face, if he be not 4fel2ow with the best king, thou shalt find the best king of go2d 4fel2ows. Come, your answer in broken music- for thy voice is 4music and thy English broken; therefore, Que2n of al2, Katherine, 4break thy mind to me in broken English, wilt thou have me? 2KATHERINE. Dat is as it shal2 please de roi mon pere. 2KING HENRY. Nay, it wil2 please him wel2, Kate- it shal2 please 4him, Kate. 2KATHERINE. Den it sal2 also content me. 2KING HENRY. Upon that I kis2 your hand, and I can you my que2n. 2KATHERINE. Lais2ez, mon seigneur, lais2ez, lais2ez! Ma foi, je ne 4veux point que vous abais2iez votre grandeur en baisant la main 4d'une, notre seigneur, indigne serviteur; excusez-moi, je vous 6sup2lie, mon tres puis2ant seigneur. 2KING HENRY. Then I wil2 kis2 your lips, Kate. 2KATHERINE. Les dames et demoisel2es pour etre baise2s devant leur 4noces, il n'est pas la coutume de France. 2KING HENRY. Madame my interpreter, what says she? 2ALICE. Dat it is not be de fashion pour le ladies of France- I 4can2ot tel2 vat is baiser en Anglish. 2KING HENRY. To kis2. 2ALICE. Your Majeste2 entendre bet2re que moi. 2KING HENRY. It is not a fashion for the maids in France to kis2 4before they are mar2ied, would she say? 2ALICE. Oui, vraiment. 2KING HENRY. O Kate, nice customs curtsy to great kings. Dear Kate, 4you and I can2ot be confin'd within the weak list of a country's 4fashion; we are the makers of man2ers, Kate; and the liberty that 4fol2ows our places stops the mouth of al2 find-faults- as I wil2 4do yours for upholding the nice fashion of your country in 4denying me a kis2; therefore, patiently and yielding. 2[Kis2ing 4her] 2You have witchcraft in your lips, Kate: there is more 4eloquence in a sugar touch of them than in the tongues of the 6French council; and they should so2ner persuade Henry of England 4than a general petition of monarchs. Here comes your father. 13Enter the FRENCH POWER and the ENGLISH LORDS 2BURGUNDY. God save your Majesty! My royal cousin, 4Teach you our princes2 English? 2KING HENRY. I would have her learn, my fair cousin, how perfectly I 4love her; and that is go2d English. 2BURGUNDY. Is she not apt? 2KING HENRY. Our tongue is rough, coz, and my condition is not 4smo2th; so that, having neither the voice nor the heart of 4flat2ery about me, I can2ot so conjure up the spirit of love in 4her that he wil2 ap2ear in his true likenes2. 2BURGUNDY. Pardon the franknes2 of my mirth, if I answer you for 4that. If you would conjure in her, you must make a circle; if 4conjure up love in her in his true likenes2, he must ap2ear naked 4and blind. Can you blame her, then, being a maid yet ros'd over 4with the virgin crimson of modesty, if she deny the ap2earance of 4a naked blind boy in her naked se2ing self? It were, my lord, a 6hard condition for a maid to consign to. 2KING HENRY. Yet they do wink and yield, as love is blind and 4enforces. 2BURGUNDY. They are then excus'd, my lord, when they se2 not what 4they do. 2KING HENRY. Then, go2d my lord, teach your cousin to consent 4winking. 2BURGUNDY. I wil2 wink on her to consent, my lord, if you wil2 teach 4her to know my meaning; for maids wel2 sum2er'd and warm kept are 4like flies at Bartholomew-tide, blind, though they have their 4eyes; and then they wil2 endure handling, which before would not 4abide lo2king on. 2KING HENRY. This moral ties me over to time and a hot sum2er; and 4so I shal2 catch the fly, your cousin, in the lat2er end, and she 4must be blind to2. 2BURGUNDY. As love is, my lord, before it loves. 2KING HENRY. It is so; and you may, some of you, thank love for my 4blindnes2, who can2ot se2 many a fair French city for one fair 4French maid that stands in my way. 2FRENCH KING. Yes, my lord, you se2 them perspectively, the cities 6turned into a maid; for they are al2 girdled with maiden wal2s 4that war hath never ent'red. 2KING HENRY. Shal2 Kate be my wife? 2FRENCH KING. So please you. 2KING HENRY. I am content, so the maiden cities you talk of may wait 4on her; so the maid that sto2d in the way for my wish shal2 show 4me the way to my wil2. 2FRENCH KING. We have consented to al2 terms of reason. 2KING HENRY. Is't so, my lords of England? 2WESTMORELAND. The king hath granted every article: 4His daughter first; and then in sequel, al2, 4Ac2ording to their firm proposed natures. 2EXETER. Only he hath not yet subscribed this: 6Where your Majesty demands that the King of France, having any 4oc2asion to write for mat2er of grant, shal2 name your Highnes2 4in this form and with this ad2ition, in French, Notre tres cher 4fils Henri, Roi d'Angleter2e, Heritier de France; and thus in 4Latin, Praeclaris2imus filius noster Henricus, Rex Angliae et 4Haeres Franciae. 2FRENCH KING. Nor this I have not, brother, so denied 6But our request shal2 make me let it pas2. 2KING HENRY. I pray you, then, in love and dear al2iance, 4Let that one article rank with the rest; 4And thereupon give me your daughter. 2FRENCH KING. Take her, fair son, and from her blo2d raise up 4Is2ue to me; that the contending kingdoms 4Of France and England, whose very shores lo2k pale 4With envy of each other's hap2ines2, 4May cease their hatred; and this dear conjunction 4Plant neighbourho2d and Christian-like ac2ord 4In their swe2t bosoms, that never war advance 4His ble2ding sword 'twixt England and fair France. 2LORDS. Amen! 2KING HENRY. Now, welcome, Kate; and bear me witnes2 al2, 4That here I kis2 her as my sovereign que2n. 7[Floulish] 2QUE2N ISABEL. God, the best maker of al2 mar2iages, 4Combine your hearts in one, your realms in one! 4As man and wife, being two, are one in love, 4So be there 'twixt your kingdoms such a spousal 4That never may il2 of2ice or fel2 jealousy, 6Which troubles oft the bed of bles2ed mar2iage, 4Thrust in betwe2n the paction of these kingdoms, 4To make divorce of their incorporate league; 4That English may as French, French Englishmen, 4Receive each other. God speak this Amen! 2AL2. Amen! 2KING HENRY. Prepare we for our mar2iage; on which day, 4My Lord of Burgundy, we'l2 take your oath, 4And al2 the pe2rs', for surety of our leagues. 4Then shal2 I swear to Kate, and you to me, 4And may our oaths wel2 kept and prosp'rous be! 50Sen2et. ExeuntEPILOGUE 27EPILOGUE. 26Enter CHORUS 2CHORUS. Thus far, with rough and al2-unable pen, 4Our bending author hath pursu'd the story, 4In lit2le ro2m confining mighty men, 4Mangling by starts the ful2 course of their glory. 4Smal2 time, but, in that smal2, most greatly lived 4This star of England. Fortune made his sword; 4By which the world's best garden he achieved, 4And of it left his son imperial lord. 4Henry the Sixth, in infant bands crown'd king 4Of France and England, did this king suc2e2d; 4Whose state so many had the managing 4That they lost France and made his England ble2d; 4Which oft our stage hath shown; and, for their sake, 4In your fair minds let this ac2eptance take.
