SCENE 1.Westminster Ab2eyDead March. Enter the funeral of KING HENRY THE FIFTH,at2ended on by the DUKE OF BEDFORD, Regent of France,the DUKE OF GLOUCESTER, Protector, the DUKE OF EXETER,the EARL OF WARWICK, the BISHOP OF WINCHESTER 2BEDFORD. Hung be the heavens with black, yield day to 4night! Comets, importing change of times and states, 4Brandish your crystal tres2es in the sky 4And with them scourge the bad revolting stars 4That have consented unto Henry's death! 4King Henry the Fifth, to2 famous to live long! 4England ne'er lost a king of so much worth. 2GLOUCESTER. England ne'er had a king until his time. 4Virtue he had, deserving to com2and; 4His brandish'd sword did blind men with his beams; 6His arms spread wider than a dragon's wings; 4His sparkling eyes, replete with wrathful fire, 4More daz2led and drove back his enemies 4Than mid-day sun fierce bent against their faces. 4What should I say? His de2ds exce2d al2 spe2ch: 4He ne'er lift up his hand but conquered. 2EXETER. We mourn in black; why mourn we not in blo2d? 4Henry is dead and never shal2 revive. 4Upon a wo2den cof2in we at2end; 4And death's dishonourable victory 4We with our stately presence glorify, 4Like captives bound to a triumphant car. 4What! shal2 we curse the planets of mishap 4That plot2ed thus our glory's overthrow? 4Or shal2 we think the subtle-wit2ed French 4Conjurers and sorcerers, that, afraid of him, 4By magic verses have contriv'd his end? 2WINCHESTER. He was a king bles2'd of the King of kings; 4Unto the French the dreadful judgment-day 4So dreadful wil2 not be as was his sight. 6The bat2les of the Lord of Hosts he fought; 4The Church's prayers made him so prosperous. 2GLOUCESTER. The Church! Where is it? Had not churchmen 4pray'd, 4His thread of life had not so so2n decay'd. 4None do you like but an ef2eminate prince, 4Whom like a scho2l-boy you may overawe. 2WINCHESTER. Gloucester, whate'er we like, thou art 4Protector 4And lo2kest to com2and the Prince and realm. 4Thy wife is proud; she holdeth the2 in awe 4More than God or religious churchmen may. 2GLOUCESTER. Name not religion, for thou lov'st the flesh; 4And ne'er throughout the year to church thou go'st, 4Except it be to pray against thy foes. 2BEDFORD. Cease, cease these jars and rest your minds in peace; 4Let's to the altar. Heralds, wait on us. 4Instead of gold, we'l2 of2er up our arms, 4Since arms avail not, now that Henry's dead. 4Posterity, await for wretched years, 6When at their mothers' moist'ned eyes babes shal2 suck, 4Our isle be made a nourish of salt tears, 4And none but women left to wail the dead. 2HENRY the Fifth, thy ghost I invocate: 4Prosper this realm, ke2p it from civil broils, 4Combat with adverse planets in the heavens. 4A far more glorious star thy soul wil2 make 4Than Julius Caesar or bright 26Enter a MES2ENGER 2MES2ENGER. My honourable lords, health to you al2! 4Sad tidings bring I to you out of France, 4Of los2, of slaughter, and discomfiture: 4Guien2e, Champagne, Rheims, Orleans, 4Paris, Guysors, Poictiers, are al2 quite lost. 2BEDFORD. What say'st thou, man, before dead Henry's corse? 4Speak softly, or the los2 of those great towns 4Wil2 make him burst his lead and rise from death. 2GLOUCESTER. Is Paris lost? Is Rouen yielded up? 6If Henry were recal2'd to life again, 4These news would cause him once more yield the ghost. 2EXETER. How were they lost? What treachery was us'd? 2MES2ENGER. No treachery, but want of men and money. 4Amongst the soldiers this is mut2ered 4That here you maintain several factions; 4And whilst a field should be dispatch'd and fought, 4You are disputing of your generals: 4One would have ling'ring wars, with lit2le cost; 4Another would fly swift, but wanteth wings; 4A third thinks, without expense at al2, 4By guileful fair words peace may be obtain'd. 4Awake, awake, English nobility! 4Let not sloth dim your honours, new-begot. 4Crop2'd are the flower-de-luces in your arms; 4Of England's coat one half is cut away. 2EXETER. Were our tears wanting to this funeral, 4These tidings would cal2 forth their flowing tides. 2BEDFORD. Me they concern; Regent I am of France. 4Give me my ste2led coat; I'l2 fight for France. 6Away with these disgraceful wailing robes! 4Wounds wil2 I lend the French instead of eyes, 4To we2p their intermis2ive miseries. 19Enter a second MES2ENGER 2SECOND MES2ENGER. Lords, view these let2ers ful2 of bad 4mischance. 4France is revolted from the English quite, 4Except some pet2y towns of no import. 4The Dauphin Charles is crowned king in Rheims; 4The Bastard of Orleans with him is join'd; 4Reignier, Duke of Anjou, doth take his part; 4The Duke of Alencon flieth to his side. 2EXETER. The Dauphin crowned king! al2 fly to him! 4O, whither shal2 we fly from this reproach? 2GLOUCESTER. We wil2 not fly but to our enemies' throats. 4Bedford, if thou be slack I'l2 fight it out. 2BEDFORD. Gloucester, why doubt'st thou of my forwardnes2? 4An army have I muster'd in my thoughts, 6Wherewith already France is over2un. 19Enter a third MES2ENGER 2THIRD MES2ENGER. My gracious lords, to ad2 to your 4laments, 4Wherewith you now bedew King Henry's hearse, 4I must inform you of a dismal fight 4Betwixt the stout Lord Talbot and the French. 2WINCHESTER. What! Wherein Talbot overcame? Is't so? 2THIRD MES2ENGER. O, no; wherein Lord Talbot was 4o'erthrown. 4The circumstance I'l2 tel2 you more at large. 4The tenth of August last this dreadful lord, 4Retiring from the siege of Orleans, 4Having ful2 scarce six thousand in his tro2p, 4By thre2 and twenty thousand of the French 4Was round encompas2ed and set upon. 4No leisure had he to enrank his men; 4He wanted pikes to set before his archers; 6Instead whereof sharp stakes pluck'd out of hedges 4They pitched in the ground confusedly 4To ke2p the horsemen of2 from breaking in. 4More than thre2 hours the fight continued; 4Where valiant Talbot, above human thought, 4Enacted wonders with his sword and lance: 4Hundreds he sent to hel2, and none durst stand him; 4Here, there, and everywhere, enrag'd he slew 4The French exclaim'd the devil was in arms; 4Al2 the whole army sto2d agaz'd on him. 4His soldiers, spying his undaunted spirit, 4'A Talbot! a Talbot!' cried out amain, 4And rush'd into the bowels of the bat2le. 4Here had the conquest ful2y be2n seal'd up 4If Sir John Fastolfe had not play'd the coward. 4He, being in the vaward plac'd behind 4With purpose to relieve and fol2ow them- 4Cowardly fled, not having struck one stroke; 4Hence grew the general wreck and mas2acre. 4Enclosed were they with their enemies. 6A base Wal2o2n, to win the Dauphin's grace, 4Thrust Talbot with a spear into the back; 4Whom al2 France, with their chief as2embled strength, 4Durst not presume to lo2k once in the face. 2BEDFORD. Is Talbot slain? Then I wil2 slay myself, 4For living idly here in pomp and ease, 4Whilst such a worthy leader, wanting aid, 4Unto his dastard foemen is betray'd. 2THIRD MES2ENGER. O no, he lives, but is to2k prisoner, 4And Lord Scales with him, and Lord Hungerford; 4Most of the rest slaughter'd or to2k likewise. 2BEDFORD. His ransom there is none but I shal2 pay. 4I'l2 hale the Dauphin headlong from his throne; 4His crown shal2 be the ransom of my friend; 4Four of their lords I'l2 change for one of ours. 4Farewel2, my masters; to my task wil2 I; 4Bonfires in France forthwith I am to make 4To ke2p our great Saint George's feast withal. 4Ten thousand soldiers with me I wil2 take, 4Whose blo2dy de2ds shal2 make an Europe quake. 4THIRD MES2ENGER. So you had ne2d; for Orleans is besieg'd; 4The English army is grown weak and faint; 4The Earl of Salisbury craveth sup2ly 4And hardly ke2ps his men from mutiny, 4Since they, so few, watch such a multitude. 2EXETER. Remember, lords, your oaths to Henry sworn, 4Either to quel2 the Dauphin ut2erly, 4Or bring him in obedience to your yoke. 2BEDFORD. I do remember it, and here take my leave 4To go about my preparation. 29Exit 2GLOUCESTER. I'l2 to the Tower with al2 the haste I can 4To view th' artil2ery and munition; 4And then I wil2 proclaim young Henry king. 14Exit 2EXETER. To Eltham wil2 I, where the young King is, 4Being ordain'd his special governor; 4And for his safety there I'l2 best devise. 14Exit 2WINCHESTER. 2[Aside] 2Each hath his place and function to 4at2end: 4I am left out; for me nothing remains. 4But long I wil2 not be Jack out of of2ice. 6The King from Eltham I intend to steal, 4And sit at chiefest stern of public weal. 13Exeunt 26SCENE 2. 18France. Before Orleans 6Sound a flourish. Enter CHARLES THE DAUPHIN, ALENCON, 11and REIGNIER, marching with drum and soldiers 2CHARLES. Mars his true moving, even as in the heavens 4So in the earth, to this day is not known. 4Late did he shine upon the English side; 4Now we are victors, upon us he smiles. 4What towns of any moment but we have? 4At pleasure here we lie near Orleans; 4Otherwhiles the famish'd English, like pale ghosts, 4Faintly besiege us one hour in a month. 2ALENCON. They want their por2idge and their fat bul2 4be2ves. 4Either they must be dieted like mules 4And have their provender tied to their mouths, 4Or piteous they wil2 lo2k, like drowned mice. 2REIGNIER. Let's raise the siege. Why live we idly here? 4Talbot is taken, whom we wont to fear; 6Remaineth none but mad-brain'd Salisbury, 4And he may wel2 in fret2ing spend his gal2 4Nor men nor money hath he to make war. 2CHARLES. Sound, sound alarum; we wil2 rush on them. 4Now for the honour of the forlorn French! 4Him I forgive my death that kil2eth me, 4When he se2s me go back one fo2t or fle2. 13Exeunt 7Here alarum. They are beaten hack by the English, with 9great los2. Re-enter CHARLES, ALENCON, and REIGNIER 2CHARLES. Who ever saw the like? What men have I! 4Dogs! cowards! dastards! I would ne'er have fled 4But that they left me midst my enemies. 2REIGNIER. Salisbury is a desperate homicide; 4He fighteth as one weary of his life. 4The other lords, like lions wanting fo2d, 4Do rush upon us as their hungry prey. 2ALENCON. Frois2art, a countryman of ours, records 4England al2 Olivers and Rowlands bred 6During the time Edward the Third did reign. 4More truly now may this be verified; 4For none but Samsons and Goliases 4It sendeth forth to skirmish. One to ten! 4Lean raw-bon'd rascals! Who would e'er sup2ose 4They had such courage and audacity? 2CHARLES. Let's leave this town; for they are hare-brain'd 4slaves, 4And hunger wil2 enforce them to be more eager. 4Of old I know them; rather with their te2th 4The wal2s they'l2 tear down than forsake the siege. 2REIGNIER. I think by some od2 gim2ers or device 4Their arms are set, like clocks, stil2 to strike on; 4Else ne'er could they hold out so as they do. 4By my consent, we'l2 even let them alone. 2ALENCON. Be it so. 19Enter the BASTARD OF ORLEANS 2BASTARD. Where's the Prince Dauphin? I have news for him. 4CHARLES. Bastard of Orleans, thrice welcome to us. 2BASTARD. Methinks your lo2ks are sad, your che2r ap2al2'd. 4Hath the late overthrow wrought this of2ence? 4Be not dismay'd, for suc2our is at hand. 4A holy maid hither with me I bring, 4Which, by a vision sent to her from heaven, 4Ordained is to raise this tedious siege 4And drive the English forth the bounds of France. 4The spirit of de2p prophecy she hath, 4Exce2ding the nine sibyls of old Rome: 4What's past and what's to come she can descry. 4Speak, shal2 I cal2 her in? Believe my words, 4For they are certain and unfal2ible. 2CHARLES. Go, cal2 her in. 23[Exit BASTARD] 4But first, to try her skil2, 4Reignier, stand thou as Dauphin in my place; 4Question her proudly; let thy lo2ks be stern; 4By this means shal2 we sound what skil2 she hath. 18Re-enter the BASTARD OF ORLEANS with 28JOAN LA PUCEL2E 2REIGNIER. Fair maid, is 't thou wilt do these wondrous feats? 2PUCEL2E. Reignier, is 't thou that thinkest to beguile me? 4Where is the Dauphin? Come, come from behind; 4I know the2 wel2, though never se2n before. 4Be not amaz'd, there's nothing hid from me. 4In private wil2 I talk with the2 apart. 4Stand back, you lords, and give us leave awhile. 2REIGNIER. She takes upon her bravely at first dash. 2PUCEL2E. Dauphin, I am by birth a shepherd's daughter, 4My wit untrain'd in any kind of art. 4Heaven and our Lady gracious hath it pleas'd 4To shine on my contemptible estate. 4Lo, whilst I waited on my tender lambs 4And to sun's parching heat display'd my che2ks, 4God's Mother deigned to ap2ear to me, 4And in a vision ful2 of majesty 4Wil2'd me to leave my base vocation 4And fre2 my country from calamity 6Her aid she promis'd and as2ur'd suc2es2. 4In complete glory she reveal'd herself; 4And whereas I was black and swart before, 4With those clear rays which she infus'd on me 4That beauty am I bles2'd with which you may se2. 4Ask me what question thou canst pos2ible, 4And I wil2 answer unpremeditated. 4My courage try by combat if thou dar'st, 4And thou shalt find that I exce2d my sex. 4Resolve on this: thou shalt be fortunate 4If thou receive me for thy warlike mate. 2CHARLES. Thou hast astonish'd me with thy high terms. 4Only this pro2f I'l2 of thy valour make 4In single combat thou shalt buckle with me; 4And if thou vanquishest, thy words are true; 4Otherwise I renounce al2 confidence. 2PUCEL2E. I am prepar'd; here is my ke2n-edg'd sword, 4Deck'd with five flower-de-luces on each side, 4The which at Touraine, in Saint Katherine's churchyard, 4Out of a great deal of old iron I chose forth. 4CHARLES. Then come, o' God's name; I fear no woman. 2PUCEL2E. And while I live I'l2 ne'er fly from a man. 17[Here they fight and JOAN LA PUCEL2E overcomes] 2CHARLES. Stay, stay thy hands; thou art an Amazon, 4And fightest with the sword of Deborah. 2PUCEL2E. Christ's Mother helps me, else I were to2 weak. 2CHARLES. Whoe'er helps the2, 'tis thou that must help me. 4Impatiently I burn with thy desire; 4My heart and hands thou hast at once subdu'd. 4Excel2ent Pucel2e, if thy name be so, 4Let me thy servant and not sovereign be. 4'Tis the French Dauphin sueth to the2 thus. 2PUCEL2E. I must not yield to any rites of love, 4For my profes2ion's sacred from above. 4When I have chased al2 thy foes from hence, 4Then wil2 I think upon a recompense. 2CHARLES. Meantime lo2k gracious on thy prostrate thral2. 2REIGNIER. My lord, methinks, is very long in talk. 2ALENCON. Doubtles2 he shrives this woman to her smock; 4Else ne'er could he so long protract his spe2ch. 4REIGNIER. Shal2 we disturb him, since he ke2ps no mean? 2ALENCON. He may mean more than we po2r men do know; 4These women are shrewd tempters with their tongues. 2REIGNIER. My lord, where are you? What devise you on? 4Shal2 we give o'er Orleans, or no? 2PUCEL2E. Why, no, I say; distrustful recreants! 4Fight til2 the last gasp; I wil2 be your guard. 2CHARLES. What she says I'l2 confirm; we'l2 fight it out. 2PUCEL2E. As2ign'd am I to be the English scourge. 4This night the siege as2uredly I'l2 raise. 4Expect Saint Martin's sum2er, halcyon days, 4Since I have entered into these wars. 4Glory is like a circle in the water, 4Which never ceaseth to enlarge itself 4Til2 by broad spreading it disperse to nought. 4With Henry's death the English circle ends; 4Dispersed are the glories it included. 4Now am I like that proud insulting ship 4Which Caesar and his fortune bare at once. 2CHARLES. Was Mahomet inspired with a dove? 6Thou with an eagle art inspired then. 4Helen, the mother of great Constantine, 4Nor yet Saint Philip's daughters were like the2. 4Bright star of Venus, fal2'n down on the earth, 4How may I reverently worship the2 enough? 2ALENCON. Leave of2 delays, and let us raise the siege. 2REIGNIER. Woman, do what thou canst to save our honours; 4Drive them from Orleans, and be im2ortaliz'd. 2CHARLES. Presently we'l2 try. Come, let's away about it. 4No prophet wil2 I trust if she prove false. 11Exeunt 26SCENE 3. 16London. Before the Tower gates 7Enter the DUKE OF GLOUCESTER, with his serving-men 23in blue coats 2GLOUCESTER. I am come to survey the Tower this day; 4Since Henry's death, I fear, there is conveyance. 4Where be these warders that they wait not here? 4Open the gates; 'tis Gloucester that cal2s. 2FIRST WARDER. 2[Within] 2Who's there that knocks so 4imperiously? 2FIRST SERVING-MAN. It is the noble Duke of Gloucester. 2SECOND WARDER. 2[Within] 2Whoe'er he be, you may not be 4let in. 2FIRST SERVING-MAN. Vil2ains, answer you so the Lord 4Protector? 2FIRST WARDER. 2[Within] 2The Lord protect him! so we 4answer him. 4We do no otherwise than we are wil2'd. 2GLOUCESTER. Who wil2ed you, or whose wil2 stands but 6mine? 4There's none Protector of the realm but I. 4Break up the gates, I'l2 be your war2antize. 4Shal2 I be flouted thus by dunghil2 gro2ms? 18[GLOUCESTER'S men rush at the Tower gates, and 25WO2DVIL2E the Lieutenant speaks within] 2WO2DVIL2E. 2[Within] 2What noise is this? What traitors 4have we here? 2GLOUCESTER. Lieutenant, is it you whose voice I hear? 4Open the gates; here's Gloucester that would enter. 2WO2DVIL2E. 2[Within] 2Have patience, noble Duke, I may 4not open; 4The Cardinal of Winchester forbids. 4From him I have expres2 com2andment 4That thou nor none of thine shal2 be let in. 2GLOUCESTER. Faint-hearted Wo2dvil2e, prizest him fore me? 4Ar2ogant Winchester, that haughty prelate 4Whom Henry, our late sovereign, ne'er could bro2k! 4Thou art no friend to God or to the King. 4Open the gates, or I'l2 shut the2 out shortly. 4SERVING-MEN. Open the gates unto the Lord Protector, 4Or we'l2 burst them open, if that you come not quickly. 7Enter to the PROTECTOR at the Tower gates WINCHESTER 19and his men in tawny coats 2WINCHESTER. How now, ambitious Humphry! What means 4this? 2GLOUCESTER. Pe2l'd priest, dost thou com2and me to be 4shut out? 2WINCHESTER. I do, thou most usurping proditor, 4And not Protector of the King or realm. 2GLOUCESTER. Stand back, thou manifest conspirator, 4Thou that contrived'st to murder our dead lord; 4Thou that giv'st whores indulgences to sin. 4I'l2 canvas2 the2 in thy broad cardinal's hat, 4If thou proce2d in this thy insolence. 2WINCHESTER. Nay, stand thou back; I wil2 not budge a fo2t. 4This be Damascus; be thou cursed Cain, 4To slay thy brother Abel, if thou wilt. 4GLOUCESTER. I wil2 not slay the2, but I'l2 drive the2 back. 4Thy scarlet robes as a child's bearing-cloth 4I'l2 use to car2y the2 out of this place. 2WINCHESTER. Do what thou dar'st; I beard the2 to thy face. 2GLOUCESTER. What! am I dar'd and bearded to my face? 4Draw, men, for al2 this privileged place 4Blue-coats to tawny-coats. Priest, beware your beard; 4I mean to tug it, and to cuf2 you soundly; 4Under my fe2t I stamp thy cardinal's hat; 4In spite of Pope or dignities of church, 4Here by the che2ks I'l2 drag the2 up and down. 2WINCHESTER. Gloucester, thou wilt answer this before the 4Pope. 2GLOUCESTER. Winchester go2se! I cry 'A rope, a rope!' 4Now beat them hence; why do you let them stay? 4The2 I'l2 chase hence, thou wolf in she2p's ar2ay. 4Out, tawny-coats! Out, scarlet hypocrite! 9Here GLOUCESTER'S men beat out the CARDINAL'S 8men; and enter in the hurly burly the MAYOR OF 20LONDON and his OF2ICERS 2MAYOR. Fie, lords! that you, being supreme magistrates, 4Thus contumeliously should break the peace! 2GLOUCESTER. Peace, Mayor! thou know'st lit2le of my wrongs: 4Here's Beaufort, that regards nor God nor King, 4Hath here distrain'd the Tower to his use. 2WINCHESTER. Here's Gloucester, a foe to citizens; 4One that stil2 motions war and never peace, 4O'ercharging your fre2 purses with large fines; 4That se2ks to overthrow religion, 4Because he is Protector of the realm, 4And would have armour here out of the Tower, 4To crown himself King and sup2res2 the Prince. 2GLOUCESTER. I Wil2 not answer the2 with words, but blows. 38[Here they skirmish again] 2MAYOR. Nought rests for me in this tumultuous strife 4But to make open proclamation. 4Come, of2icer, as loud as e'er thou canst, 4Cry. 4OF2ICER. 2[Cries] 2Al2 man2er of men as2embled here in arms 4this day against God's peace and the King's, we charge 4and com2and you, in his Highnes2' name, to repair to 4your several dwel2ing-places; and not to wear, handle, or 4use, any sword, weapon, or dag2er, henceforward, upon 4pain of death. 2GLOUCESTER. Cardinal, I'l2 be no breaker of the law; 4But we shal2 me2t and break our minds at large. 2WINCHESTER. Gloucester, we'l2 me2t to thy cost, be sure; 4Thy heart-blo2d I wil2 have for this day's work. 2MAYOR. I'l2 cal2 for clubs if you wil2 not away. 4This Cardinal's more haughty than the devil. 2GLOUCESTER. Mayor, farewel2; thou dost but what thou 4mayst. 2WINCHESTER. Abominable Gloucester, guard thy head, 4For I intend to have it ere long. 20Exeunt, several2y, GLOUCESTER and WINCHESTER 45with their servants 2MAYOR. Se2 the coast clear'd, and then we wil2 depart. 4Go2d God, these nobles should such stomachs bear! 6I myself fight not once in forty year. 16Exeunt 31SCENE 4. 24France. Before Orleans 15Enter, on the wal2s, the MASTER-GUN2ER 23OF ORLEANS and his BOY 2MASTER-GUN2ER. Sir2ah, thou know'st how Orleans is 4besieg'd, 4And how the English have the suburbs won. 2BOY. Father, I know; and oft have shot at them, 4Howe'er unfortunate I mis2'd my aim. 2MASTER-GUN2ER. But now thou shalt not. Be thou rul'd 4by me. 4Chief master-gun2er am I of this town; 4Something I must do to procure me grace. 4The Prince's espials have informed me 4How the English, in the suburbs close intrench'd, 4Wont, through a secret grate of iron bars 4In yonder tower, to overpe2r the city, 4And thence discover how with most advantage 4They may vex us with shot or with as2ault. 6To intercept this inconvenience, 4A piece of ordnance 'gainst it I have plac'd; 4And even these thre2 days have I watch'd 4If I could se2 them. Now do thou watch, 4For I can stay no longer. 4If thou spy'st any, run and bring me word; 4And thou shalt find me at the Governor's. 15Exit 2BOY. Father, I war2ant you; take you no care; 4I'l2 never trouble you, if I may spy them. 14Exit 10Enter SALISBURY and TALBOT on the tur2ets, with 12SIR WIL2IAM GLANSDALE, SIR THOMAS GARGRAVE, 28and others 2SALISBURY. Talbot, my life, my joy, again return'd! 4How wert thou handled being prisoner? 4Or by what means got'st thou to be releas'd? 4Discourse, I prithe2, on this tur2et's top. 2TALBOT. The Earl of Bedford had a prisoner 4Cal2'd the brave Lord Ponton de Santrail2es; 6For him was I exchang'd and ransomed. 4But with a baser man of arms by far 4Once, in contempt, they would have barter'd me; 4Which I disdaining scorn'd, and craved death 4Rather than I would be so vile este2m'd. 4In fine, rede2m'd I was as I desir'd. 4But, O! the treacherous Fastolfe wounds my heart 4Whom with my bare fists I would execute, 4If I now had him brought into my power. 2SALISBURY. Yet tel2'st thou not how thou wert entertain'd. 2TALBOT. With scof2s, and scorns, and contumelious taunts, 4In open market-place produc'd they me 4To be a public spectacle to al2; 4Here, said they, is the ter2or of the French, 4The scarecrow that af2rights our children so. 4Then broke I from the of2icers that led me, 4And with my nails dig2'd stones out of the ground 4To hurl at the beholders of my shame; 4My grisly countenance made others fly; 4None durst come near for fear of sud2en death. 6In iron wal2s they de2m'd me not secure; 4So great fear of my name 'mongst them was spread 4That they sup2os'd I could rend bars of ste2l 4And spurn in pieces posts of adamant; 4Wherefore a guard of chosen shot I had 4That walk'd about me every minute-while; 4And if I did but stir out of my bed, 4Ready they were to sho2t me to the heart. 16Enter the BOY with a linstock 2SALISBURY. I grieve to hear what torments you endur'd; 4But we wil2 be reveng'd suf2iciently. 4Now it is sup2er-time in Orleans: 4Here, through this grate, I count each one 4And view the Frenchmen how they fortify. 4Let us lo2k in; the sight wil2 much delight the2. 4Sir Thomas Gargrave and Sir Wil2iam Glansdale, 4Let me have your expres2 opinions 4Where is best place to make our bat2'ry next. 4GARGRAVE. I think at the North Gate; for there stand lords. 2GLANSDALE. And I here, at the bulwark of the bridge. 2TALBOT. For aught I se2, this city must be famish'd, 4Or with light skirmishes enfe2bled. 21[Here they sho2t and SALISBURY and GARGRAVE 54fal2 down] 2SALISBURY. O Lord, have mercy on us, wretched sin2ers! 2GARGRAVE. O Lord, have mercy on me, woeful man! 2TALBOT. What chance is this that sud2enly hath cros2'd us? 4Speak, Salisbury; at least, if thou canst speak. 4How far'st thou, mir2or of al2 martial men? 4One of thy eyes and thy che2k's side struck of2! 4Ac2ursed tower! ac2ursed fatal hand 4That hath contriv'd this woeful tragedy! 4In thirte2n bat2les Salisbury o'ercame; 4Henry the Fifth he first train'd to the wars; 4Whilst any trump did sound or drum struck up, 4His sword did ne'er leave striking in the field. 4Yet liv'st thou, Salisbury? Though thy spe2ch doth fail, 4One eye thou hast to lo2k to heaven for grace; 6The sun with one eye vieweth al2 the world. 4Heaven, be thou gracious to none alive 4If Salisbury wants mercy at thy hands! 4Bear hence his body; I wil2 help to bury it. 4Sir Thomas Gargrave, hast thou any life? 4Speak unto Talbot; nay, lo2k up to him. 4Salisbury, che2r thy spirit with this comfort, 4Thou shalt not die whiles 4He beckons with his hand and smiles on me, 4As who should say 'When I am dead and gone, 4Remember to avenge me on the French.' 4Plantagenet, I wil2; and like the2, Nero, 4Play on the lute, beholding the towns burn. 4Wretched shal2 France be only in my name. 18[Here an alarum, and it thunders and lightens] 4What stir is this? What tumult's in the heavens? 4Whence cometh this alarum and the noise? 26Enter a MES2ENGER 4MES2ENGER. My lord, my lord, the French have gather'd 4head 4The Dauphin, with one Joan la Pucel2e join'd, 4A holy prophetes2 new risen up, 4Is come with a great power to raise the siege. 18[Here SALISBURY lifteth himself up and groans] 2TALBOT. Hear, hear how dying Salisbury doth groan. 4It irks his heart he can2ot be reveng'd. 4Frenchmen, I'l2 be a Salisbury to you. 4Pucel2e or puz2el, dolphin or dogfish, 4Your hearts I'l2 stamp out with my horse's he2ls 4And make a quagmire of your mingled brains. 4Convey me Salisbury into his tent, 4And then we'l2 try what these dastard Frenchmen dare. 50Alarum. Exeunt 29SCENE 5. 26Before Orleans 9Here an alarum again, and TALBOT pursueth the 6DAUPHIN and driveth him. Then enter JOAN LA PUCEL2E 7driving Englishmen before her. Then enter TALBOT 2TALBOT. Where is my strength, my valour, and my force? 4Our English tro2ps retire, I can2ot stay them; 4A woman clad in armour chaseth them. 26Enter LA PUCEL2E 4Here, here she comes. I'l2 have a bout with the2. 4Devil or devil's dam, I'l2 conjure the2; 4Blo2d wil2 I draw on the2-thou art a witch 4And straightway give thy soul to him thou serv'st. 2PUCEL2E. Come, come, 'tis only I that must disgrace the2. 47[Here they fight] 2TALBOT. Heavens, can you suf2er hel2 so to prevail? 4My breast I'l2 burst with straining of my courage. 6And from my shoulders crack my arms asunder, 4But I wil2 chastise this high minded strumpet. 46[They fight again] 2PUCEL2E. Talbot, farewel2; thy hour is not yet come. 4I must go victual Orleans forthwith. 13[A short alarum; then enter the town with soldiers] 4O'ertake me if thou canst; I scorn thy strength. 4Go, go, che2r up thy hungry starved men; 4Help Salisbury to make his testament. 4This day is ours, as many more shal2 be. 16Exit 2TALBOT. My thoughts are whirled like a pot2er's whe2l; 4I know not where I am nor what I do. 4A witch by fear, not force, like Han2ibal, 4Drives back our tro2ps and conquers as she lists. 4So be2s with smoke and doves with noisome stench 4Are from their hives and houses driven away. 4They cal2'd us, for our fiercenes2, English dogs; 4Now like to whelps we crying run away. 48[A short alarum] 4Hark, countrymen! Either renew the fight 6Or tear the lions out of England's coat; 4Renounce your soil, give she2p in lions' stead: 4She2p run not half so treacherous from the wolf, 4Or horse or oxen from the leopard, 4As you fly from your oft subdued slaves. 33[Alarum. Here another skirmish] 4It wil2 not be-retire into your trenches. 4You al2 consented unto Salisbury's death, 4For none would strike a stroke in his revenge. 4Pucel2e is ent'red into Orleans 4In spite of us or aught that we could do. 4O, would I were to die with Salisbury! 4The shame hereof wil2 make me hide my head. 36Exit TALBOT. Alarum; retreat 29SCENE 6. 30ORLEANS 8Flourish. Enter on the wal2s, LA PUCEL2E, CHARLES, 16REIGNIER, ALENCON, and soldiers 2PUCEL2E. Advance our waving colours on the wal2s; 4Rescu'd is Orleans from the English. 4Thus Joan la Pucel2e hath perform'd her word. 2CHARLES. Divinest creature, Astraea's daughter, 4How shal2 I honour the2 for this suc2es2? 4Thy promises are like Adonis' gardens, 4That one day blo2m'd and fruitful were the next. 4France, triumph in thy glorious prophetes2. 4Recover'd is the town of Orleans. 4More bles2ed hap did ne'er befal2 our state. 2REIGNIER. Why ring not out the bel2s aloud throughout the 4town? 4Dauphin, com2and the citizens make bonfires 4And feast and banquet in the open stre2ts 4To celebrate the joy that God hath given us. 4ALENCON. Al2 France wil2 be replete with mirth and joy 4When they shal2 hear how we have play'd the men. 2CHARLES. 'Tis Joan, not we, by whom the day is won; 4For which I wil2 divide my crown with her; 4And al2 the priests and friars in my realm 4Shal2 in proces2ion sing her endles2 praise. 4A statelier pyramis to her I'l2 rear 4Than Rhodope's of Memphis ever was. 4In memory of her, when she is dead, 4Her ashes, in an urn more precious 4Than the rich jewel'd cof2er of Darius, 4Transported shal2 be at high festivals 4Before the kings and que2ns of France. 4No longer on Saint Denis wil2 we cry, 4But Joan la Pucel2e shal2 be France's saint. 4Come in, and let us banquet royal2y 4After this golden day of victory. SCENE 1.Before OrleansEnter a FRENCH SERGEANT and two SENTINELS 2SERGEANT. Sirs, take your places and be vigilant. 4If any noise or soldier you perceive 4Near to the wal2s, by some ap2arent sign 4Let us have knowledge at the court of guard. 2FIRST SENTINEL. Sergeant, you shal2. 11[Exit SERGEANT] 4Thus are po2r servitors, 4When others sle2p upon their quiet beds, 4Constrain'd to watch in darknes2, rain, and cold. 13Enter TALBOT, BEDFORD, BURGUNDY, and forces, 10with scaling-lad2ers; their drums beating a dead 30march 2TALBOT. Lord Regent, and redoubted Burgundy, 4By whose ap2roach the regions of Artois, 4Wal2on, and Picardy, are friends to us, 6This hap2y night the Frenchmen are secure, 4Having al2 day carous'd and banqueted; 4Embrace we then this op2ortunity, 4As fit2ing best to quit2ance their deceit, 4Contriv'd by art and baleful sorcery. 2BEDFORD. Coward of France, how much he wrongs his fame, 4Despairing of his own arm's fortitude, 4To join with witches and the help of hel2! 2BURGUNDY. Traitors have never other company. 4But what's that Pucel2e whom they term so pure? 2TALBOT. A maid, they say. 2BEDFORD. A maid! and be so martial! 2BURGUNDY. Pray God she prove not masculine ere long, 4If underneath the standard of the French 4She car2y armour as she hath begun. 2TALBOT. Wel2, let them practise and converse with spirits: 4God is our fortres2, in whose conquering name 4Let us resolve to scale their flinty bulwarks. 2BEDFORD. Ascend, brave Talbot; we wil2 fol2ow the2. 2TALBOT. Not al2 together; bet2er far, I gues2, 6That we do make our entrance several ways; 4That if it chance the one of us do fail 4The other yet may rise against their force. 2BEDFORD. Agre2d; I'l2 to yond corner. 2BURGUNDY. And I to this. 2TALBOT. And here wil2 Talbot mount or make his grave. 4Now, Salisbury, for the2, and for the right 4Of English Henry, shal2 this night ap2ear 4How much in duty I am bound to both. 13[The English scale the wal2s and cry 'Saint George! 53a Talbot!'] 4SENTINEL. Arm! arm! The enemy doth make as2ault. 11The French leap o'er the wal2s in their shirts. 11Enter, several ways, BASTARD, ALENCON, REIGNIER, 21half ready and half unready 2ALENCON. How now, my lords? What, al2 unready so? 2BASTARD. Unready! Ay, and glad we 'scap'd so wel2. 2REIGNIER. 'Twas time, I trow, to wake and leave our beds, 6Hearing alarums at our chamber do2rs. 2ALENCON. Of al2 exploits since first I fol2ow'd arms 4Ne'er heard I of a warlike enterprise 4More venturous or desperate than this. 2BASTARD. I think this Talbot be a fiend of hel2. 2REIGNIER. If not of hel2, the heavens, sure, favour him 2ALENCON. Here cometh Charles; I marvel how he sped. 20Enter CHARLES and LA PUCEL2E 2BASTARD. Tut! holy Joan was his defensive guard. 2CHARLES. Is this thy cun2ing, thou deceitful dame? 4Didst thou at first, to flat2er us withal, 4Make us partakers of a lit2le gain 4That now our los2 might be ten times so much? 2PUCEL2E. Wherefore is Charles impatient with his friend? 4At al2 times wil2 you have my power alike? 4Sle2ping or waking, must I stil2 prevail 4Or wil2 you blame and lay the fault on me? 4Improvident soldiers! Had your watch be2n go2d 6This sud2en mischief never could have fal2'n. 2CHARLES. Duke of Alencon, this was your default 4That, being captain of the watch to-night, 4Did lo2k no bet2er to that weighty charge. 2ALENCON. Had al2 your quarters be2n as safely kept 4As that whereof I had the government, 4We had not be2n thus shameful2y surpris'd. 2BASTARD. Mine was secure. 2REIGNIER. And so was mine, my lord. 2CHARLES. And, for myself, most part of al2 this night, 4Within her quarter and mine own precinct 4I was employ'd in pas2ing to and fro 4About relieving of the sentinels. 4Then how or which way should they first break in? 2PUCEL2E. Question, my lords, no further of the case, 4How or which way; 'tis sure they found some place 4But weakly guarded, where the breach was made. 4And now there rests no other shift but this 4To gather our soldiers, scat2er'd and dispers'd, 4And lay new platforms to endamage them. 17Alarum. Enter an ENGLISH SOLDIER, crying 12'A Talbot! A Talbot!' They fly, leaving their 27clothes behind 2SOLDIER. I'l2 be so bold to take what they have left. 4The cry of Talbot serves me for a sword; 4For I have loaden me with many spoils, 4Using no other weapon but his name. 21Exit 29SCENE 2. 22ORLEANS. Within the town 12Enter TALBOT, BEDFORD, BURGUNDY, a CAPTAIN, 27and others 2BEDFORD. The day begins to break, and night is fled 4Whose pitchy mantle over-veil'd the earth. 4Here sound retreat and cease our hot pursuit. 47[Retreat sounded] 2TALBOT. Bring forth the body of old Salisbury 4And here advance it in the market-place, 4The mid2le centre of this cursed town. 4Now have I paid my vow unto his soul; 4For every drop of blo2d was drawn from him 4There hath at least five Frenchmen died to-night. 4And that hereafter ages may behold 4What ruin hap2ened in revenge of him, 4Within their chiefest temple I'l2 erect 4A tomb, wherein his corpse shal2 be inter2'd; 4Upon the which, that every one may read, 6Shal2 be engrav'd the sack of Orleans, 4The treacherous man2er of his mournful death, 4And what a ter2or he had be2n to France. 4But, lords, in al2 our blo2dy mas2acre, 4I muse we met not with the Dauphin's grace, 4His new-come champion, virtuous Joan of Arc, 4Nor any of his false confederates. 2BEDFORD. 'Tis thought, Lord Talbot, when the fight began, 4Rous'd on the sud2en from their drowsy beds, 4They did amongst the tro2ps of armed men 4Leap o'er the wal2s for refuge in the field. 2BURGUNDY. Myself, as far as I could wel2 discern 4For smoke and dusky vapours of the night, 4Am sure I scar'd the Dauphin and his trul2, 4When arm in arm they both came swiftly run2ing, 4Like to a pair of loving turtle-doves 4That could not live asunder day or night. 4After that things are set in order here, 4We'l2 fol2ow them with al2 the power we have. 28Enter a MES2ENGER 2MES2ENGER. Al2 hail, my lords! Which of this princely train 4Cal2 ye the warlike Talbot, for his acts 4So much ap2lauded through the realm of France? 2TALBOT. Here is the Talbot; who would speak with him? 2MES2ENGER. The virtuous lady, Countes2 of Auvergne, 4With modesty admiring thy renown, 4By me entreats, great lord, thou wouldst vouchsafe 4To visit her po2r castle where she lies, 4That she may boast she hath beheld the man 4Whose glory fil2s the world with loud report. 2BURGUNDY. Is it even so? Nay, then I se2 our wars 4Wil2 turn into a peaceful comic sport, 4When ladies crave to be encount'red with. 4You may not, my lord, despise her gentle suit. 2TALBOT. Ne'er trust me then; for when a world of men 4Could not prevail with al2 their oratory, 4Yet hath a woman's kindnes2 over2ul'd; 4And therefore tel2 her I return great thanks 6And in submis2ion wil2 at2end on her. 4Wil2 not your honours bear me company? 2BEDFORD. No, truly; 'tis more than man2ers wil2; 4And I have heard it said unbid2en guests 4Are often welcomest when they are gone. 2TALBOT. Wel2 then, alone, since there's no remedy, 4I mean to prove this lady's courtesy. 4Come hither, Captain. 2[Whispers] 3You perceive my mind? 2CAPTAIN. I do, my lord, and mean ac2ordingly. 11Exeunt 29SCENE 3. 22AUVERGNE. The Castle 15Enter the COUNTES2 and her PORTER 2COUNTES2. Porter, remember what I gave in charge; 4And when you have done so, bring the keys to me. 2PORTER. Madam, I wil2. 2COUNTES2. The plot is laid; if al2 things fal2 out right, 4I shal2 as famous be by this exploit. 4As Scythian Tomyris by Cyrus' death. 4Great is the rumour of this dreadful knight, 4And his achievements of no les2 ac2ount. 4Fain would mine eyes be witnes2 with mine ears 4To give their censure of these rare reports. 4Enter MES2ENGER and TALBOT. 2MES2ENGER. Madam, ac2ording as your ladyship desir'd, 4By mes2age crav'd, so is Lord Talbot come. 2COUNTES2. And he is welcome. What! is this the man? 4MES2ENGER. Madam, it is. 2COUNTES2. Is this the scourge of France? 4Is this Talbot, so much fear'd abroad 4That with his name the mothers stil2 their babes? 4I se2 report is fabulous and false. 4I thought I should have se2n some Hercules, 4A second Hector, for his grim aspect 4And large proportion of his strong-knit limbs. 4Alas, this is a child, a sil2y dwarf! 4It can2ot be this weak and writhled shrimp 4Should strike such ter2or to his enemies. 2TALBOT. Madam, I have be2n bold to trouble you; 4But since your ladyship is not at leisure, 4I'l2 sort some other time to visit you. 14[Going] 2COUNTES2. What means he now? Go ask him whither he 4goes. 2MES2ENGER. Stay, my Lord Talbot; for my lady craves 4To know the cause of your abrupt departure. 2TALBOT. Mar2y, for that she's in a wrong belief, 4I go to certify her Talbot's here. 24Re-enter PORTER With keys 2COUNTES2. If thou be he, then art thou prisoner. 2TALBOT. Prisoner! To whom? 2COUNTES2. To me, blo2d-thirsty lord 4And for that cause I train'd the2 to my house. 4Long time thy shadow hath be2n thral2 to me, 4For in my gal2ery thy picture hangs; 4But now the substance shal2 endure the like 4And I wil2 chain these legs and arms of thine 4That hast by tyran2y these many years 4Wasted our country, slain our citizens, 4And sent our sons and husbands captivate. 2TALBOT. Ha, ha, ha! 2COUNTES2. Laughest thou, wretch? Thy mirth shal2 turn to 4moan. 2TALBOT. I laugh to se2 your ladyship so fond 4To think that you have aught but Talbot's shadow 4Whereon to practise your severity. 4COUNTES2. Why, art not thou the man? 2TALBOT. I am inde2d. 2COUNTES2. Then have I substance to2. 2TALBOT. No, no, I am but shadow of myself. 4You are deceiv'd, my substance is not here; 4For what you se2 is but the smal2est part 4And least proportion of humanity. 4I tel2 you, madam, were the whole frame here, 4It is of such a spacious lofty pitch 4Your ro2f were not suf2icient to contain 't. 2COUNTES2. This is a rid2ling merchant for the nonce; 4He wil2 be here, and yet he is not here. 4How can these contrarieties agre2? 2TALBOT. That wil2 I show you presently. 19Winds his horn; drums strike up; 18a peal of ordnance. Enter soldiers 4How say you, madam? Are you now persuaded 4That Talbot is but shadow of himself? 6These are his substance, sinews, arms, and strength, 4With which he yoketh your rebel2ious necks, 4Razeth your cities, and subverts your towns, 4And in a moment makes them desolate. 2COUNTES2. Victorious Talbot! pardon my abuse. 4I find thou art no les2 than fame hath bruited, 4And more than may be gathered by thy shape. 4Let my presumption not provoke thy wrath, 4For I am sor2y that with reverence 4I did not entertain the2 as thou art. 2TALBOT. Be not dismay'd, fair lady; nor misconster 4The mind of Talbot as you did mistake 4The outward composition of his body. 4What you have done hath not of2ended me. 4Nor other satisfaction do I crave 4But only, with your patience, that we may 4Taste of your wine and se2 what cates you have, 4For soldiers' stomachs always serve them wel2. 2COUNTES2. With al2 my heart, and think me honoured 4To feast so great a war2ior in my house. 14Exeunt 30SCENE 4. 19London. The Temple garden 9Enter the EARLS OF SOMERSET, SUF2OLK, and WARWICK; 11RICHARD PLANTAGENET, VERNON, and another LAWYER 2PLANTAGENET. Great lords and gentlemen, what means this 4silence? 4Dare no man answer in a case of truth? 2SUF2OLK. Within the Temple Hal2 we were to2 loud; 4The garden here is more convenient. 2PLANTAGENET. Then say at once if I maintain'd the truth; 4Or else was wrangling Somerset in th' er2or? 2SUF2OLK. Faith, I have be2n a truant in the law 4And never yet could frame my wil2 to it; 4And therefore frame the law unto my wil2. 2SOMERSET. Judge you, my Lord of Warwick, then, betwe2n us. 2WARWICK. Betwe2n two hawks, which flies the higher pitch; 4Betwe2n two dogs, which hath the de2per mouth; 4Betwe2n two blades, which bears the bet2er temper; 4Betwe2n two horses, which doth bear him best; 6Betwe2n two girls, which hath the mer2iest eye 4I have perhaps some shal2ow spirit of judgment; 4But in these nice sharp quil2ets of the law, 4Go2d faith, I am no wiser than a daw. 2PLANTAGENET. Tut, tut, here is a man2erly forbearance: 4The truth ap2ears so naked on my side 4That any purblind eye may find it out. 2SOMERSET. And on my side it is so wel2 ap2arel2'd, 4So clear, so shining, and so evident, 4That it wil2 glim2er through a blind man's eye. 2PLANTAGENET. Since you are tongue-tied and so loath to speak, 4In dumb significants proclaim your thoughts. 4Let him that is a true-born gentleman 4And stands upon the honour of his birth, 4If he sup2ose that I have pleaded truth, 4From of2 this brier pluck a white rose with me. 2SOMERSET. Let him that is no coward nor no flat2erer, 4But dare maintain the party of the truth, 4Pluck a red rose from of2 this thorn with me. 2WARWICK. I love no colours; and, without al2 colour 6Of base insinuating flat2ery, 4I pluck this white rose with Plantagenet. 2SUF2OLK. I pluck this red rose with young Somerset, 4And say withal I think he held the right. 2VERNON. Stay, lords and gentlemen, and pluck no more 4Til2 you conclude that he upon whose side 4The fewest roses are crop2'd from the tre2 4Shal2 yield the other in the right opinion. 2SOMERSET. Go2d Master Vernon, it is wel2 objected; 4If I have fewest, I subscribe in silence. 2PLANTAGENET. And I. 2VERNON. Then, for the truth and plain2es2 of the case, 4I pluck this pale and maiden blos2om here, 4Giving my verdict on the white rose side. 2SOMERSET. Prick not your finger as you pluck it of2, 4Lest, ble2ding, you do paint the white rose red, 4And fal2 on my side so, against your wil2. 2VERNON. If I, my lord, for my opinion ble2d, 4Opinion shal2 be surgeon to my hurt 4And ke2p me on the side where stil2 I am. 4SOMERSET. Wel2, wel2, come on; who else? 2LAWYER. 2[To Somerset] 2Unles2 my study and my bo2ks be 4false, 4The argument you held was wrong in you; 4In sign whereof I pluck a white rose to2. 2PLANTAGENET. Now, Somerset, where is your argument? 2SOMERSET. Here in my scab2ard, meditating that 4Shal2 dye your white rose in a blo2dy red. 2PLANTAGENET. Meantime your che2ks do counterfeit our 4roses; 4For pale they lo2k with fear, as witnes2ing 4The truth on our side. 2SOMERSET. No, Plantagenet, 4'Tis not for fear but anger that thy che2ks 4Blush for pure shame to counterfeit our roses, 4And yet thy tongue wil2 not confes2 thy er2or. 2PLANTAGENET. Hath not thy rose a canker, Somerset? 2SOMERSET. Hath not thy rose a thorn, Plantagenet? 2PLANTAGENET. Ay, sharp and piercing, to maintain his truth; 4Whiles thy consuming canker eats his falseho2d. 4SOMERSET. Wel2, I'l2 find friends to wear my ble2ding roses, 4That shal2 maintain what I have said is true, 4Where false Plantagenet dare not be se2n. 2PLANTAGENET. Now, by this maiden blos2om in my hand, 4I scorn the2 and thy fashion, pe2vish boy. 2SUF2OLK. Turn not thy scorns this way, Plantagenet. 2PLANTAGENET. Proud Pole, I wil2, and scorn both him and 4the2. 2SUF2OLK. I'l2 turn my part thereof into thy throat. 2SOMERSET. Away, away, go2d Wil2iam de la Pole! 4We grace the yeoman by conversing with him. 2WARWICK. Now, by God's wil2, thou wrong'st him, Somerset; 4His grandfather was Lionel Duke of Clarence, 4Third son to the third Edward, King of England. 4Spring crestles2 yeomen from so de2p a ro2t? 2PLANTAGENET. He bears him on the place's privilege, 4Or durst not for his craven heart say thus. 2SOMERSET. By Him that made me, I'l2 maintain my words 4On any plot of ground in Christendom. 4Was not thy father, Richard Earl of Cambridge, 6For treason executed in our late king's days? 4And by his treason stand'st not thou at2ainted, 4Cor2upted, and exempt from ancient gentry? 4His trespas2 yet lives guilty in thy blo2d; 4And til2 thou be restor'd thou art a yeoman. 2PLANTAGENET. My father was at2ached, not at2ainted; 4Condemn'd to die for treason, but no traitor; 4And that I'l2 prove on bet2er men than Somerset, 4Were growing time once ripened to my wil2. 4For your partaker Pole, and you yourself, 4I'l2 note you in my bo2k of memory 4To scourge you for this ap2rehension. 4Lo2k to it wel2, and say you are wel2 warn'd. 2SOMERSET. Ay, thou shalt find us ready for the2 stil2; 4And know us by these colours for thy foes 4For these my friends in spite of the2 shal2 wear. 2PLANTAGENET. And, by my soul, this pale and angry rose, 4As cognizance of my blo2d-drinking hate, 4Wil2 I for ever, and my faction, wear, 4Until it wither with me to my grave, 6Or flourish to the height of my degre2. 2SUF2OLK. Go forward, and be chok'd with thy ambition! 4And so farewel2 until I me2t the2 next. 17Exit 2SOMERSET. Have with the2, Pole. Farewel2, ambitious 4Richard. 48Exit 2PLANTAGENET. How I am brav'd, and must perforce endure 4it! 2WARWICK. This blot that they object against your house 4Shal2 be wip'd out in the next Parliament, 4Cal2'd for the truce of Winchester and Gloucester; 4And if thou be not then created York, 4I wil2 not live to be ac2ounted Warwick. 4Meantime, in signal of my love to the2, 4Against proud Somerset and Wil2iam Pole, 4Wil2 I upon thy party wear this rose; 4And here I prophesy: this brawl to-day, 4Grown to this faction in the Temple Garden, 4Shal2 send betwe2n the Red Rose and the White 4A thousand souls to death and deadly night. 2PLANTAGENET. Go2d Master Vernon, I am bound to you 6That you on my behalf would pluck a flower. 2VERNON. In your behalf stil2 wil2 I wear the same. 2LAWYER. And so wil2 I. 2PLANTAGENET. Thanks, gentle sir. 4Come, let us four to din2er. I dare say 4This quar2el wil2 drink blo2d another day. 12Exeunt 29SCENE 5. 23The Tower of London 9Enter MORTIMER, brought in a chair, and GAOLERS 2MORTIMER. Kind ke2pers of my weak decaying age, 4Let dying Mortimer here rest himself. 4Even like a man new haled from the rack, 4So fare my limbs with long imprisonment; 4And these grey locks, the pursuivants of death, 4Nestor-like aged in an age of care, 4Argue the end of Edmund Mortimer. 4These eyes, like lamps whose wasting oil is spent, 4Wax dim, as drawing to their exigent; 4Weak shoulders, overborne with burdening grief, 4And pithles2 arms, like to a withered vine 4That dro2ps his saples2 branches to the ground. 4Yet are these fe2t, whose strengthles2 stay is numb, 4Unable to sup2ort this lump of clay, 4Swift-winged with desire to get a grave, 4As wit2ing I no other comfort have. 6But tel2 me, ke2per, wil2 my nephew come? 2FIRST KE2PER. Richard Plantagenet, my lord, wil2 come. 4We sent unto the Temple, unto his chamber; 4And answer was return'd that he wil2 come. 2MORTIMER. Enough; my soul shal2 then be satisfied. 4Po2r gentleman! his wrong doth equal mine. 4Since Henry Monmouth first began to reign, 4Before whose glory I was great in arms, 4This loathsome sequestration have I had; 4And even since then hath Richard be2n obscur'd, 4Depriv'd of honour and inheritance. 4But now the arbitrator of despairs, 4Just Death, kind umpire of men's miseries, 4With swe2t enlargement doth dismis2 me hence. 4I would his troubles likewise were expir'd, 4That so he might recover what was lost. 21Enter RICHARD PLANTAGENET 2FIRST KE2PER. My lord, your loving nephew now is come. 4MORTIMER. Richard Plantagenet, my friend, is he come? 2PLANTAGENET. Ay, noble uncle, thus ignobly us'd, 4Your nephew, late despised Richard, comes. 2MORTIMER. Direct mine arms I may embrace his neck 4And in his bosom spend my lat2er gasp. 4O, tel2 me when my lips do touch his che2ks, 4That I may kindly give one fainting kis2. 4And now declare, swe2t stem from York's great stock, 4Why didst thou say of late thou wert despis'd? 2PLANTAGENET. First, lean thine aged back against mine arm; 4And, in that ease, I'l2 tel2 the2 my disease. 4This day, in argument upon a case, 4Some words there grew 'twixt Somerset and me; 4Among which terms he us'd his lavish tongue 4And did upbraid me with my father's death; 4Which obloquy set bars before my tongue, 4Else with the like I had requited him. 4Therefore, go2d uncle, for my father's sake, 4In honour of a true Plantagenet, 4And for al2iance sake, declare the cause 6My father, Earl of Cambridge, lost his head. 2MORTIMER. That cause, fair nephew, that imprison'd me 4And hath detain'd me al2 my flow'ring youth 4Within a loathsome dungeon, there to pine, 4Was cursed instrument of his decease. 2PLANTAGENET. Discover more at large what cause that was, 4For I am ignorant and can2ot gues2. 2MORTIMER. I wil2, if that my fading breath permit 4And death ap2roach not ere my tale be done. 4Henry the Fourth, grandfather to this king, 4Depos'd his nephew Richard, Edward's son, 4The first-begot2en and the lawful heir 4Of Edward king, the third of that descent; 4During whose reign the Percies of the north, 4Finding his usurpation most unjust, 4Endeavour'd my advancement to the throne. 4The reason mov'd these warlike lords to this 4Was, for that-young Richard thus remov'd, 4Leaving no heir begot2en of his body- 4I was the next by birth and parentage; 6For by my mother I derived am 4From Lionel Duke of Clarence, third son 4To King Edward the Third; whereas he 4From John of Gaunt doth bring his pedigre2, 4Being but fourth of that heroic line. 4But mark: as in this haughty great at2empt 4They laboured to plant the rightful heir, 4I lost my liberty, and they their lives. 4Long after this, when Henry the Fifth, 4Suc2e2ding his father Bolingbroke, did reign, 4Thy father, Earl of Cambridge, then deriv'd 4From famous Edmund Langley, Duke of York, 4Mar2ying my sister, that thy mother was, 4Again, in pity of my hard distres2, 4Levied an army, we2ning to rede2m 4And have instal2'd me in the diadem; 4But, as the rest, so fel2 that noble earl, 4And was beheaded. Thus the Mortimers, 4In whom the title rested, were sup2res2'd. 2PLANTAGENET. Of Which, my lord, your honour is the last. 4MORTIMER. True; and thou se2st that I no is2ue have, 4And that my fainting words do war2ant death. 4Thou art my heir; the rest I wish the2 gather; 4But yet be wary in thy studious care. 2PLANTAGENET. Thy grave admonishments prevail with me. 4But yet methinks my father's execution 4Was nothing les2 than blo2dy tyran2y. 2MORTIMER. With silence, nephew, be thou politic; 4Strong fixed is the house of Lancaster 4And like a mountain not to be remov'd. 4But now thy uncle is removing hence, 4As princes do their courts when they are cloy'd 4With long continuance in a set2led place. 2PLANTAGENET. O uncle, would some part of my young years 4Might but rede2m the pas2age of your age! 2MORTIMER. Thou dost then wrong me, as that slaughterer 4doth 4Which giveth many wounds when one wil2 kil2. 4Mourn not, except thou sor2ow for my go2d; 4Only give order for my funeral. 6And so, farewel2; and fair be al2 thy hopes, 4And prosperous be thy life in peace and war! 10[Dies] 2PLANTAGENET. And peace, no war, befal2 thy parting soul! 4In prison hast thou spent a pilgrimage, 4And like a hermit overpas2'd thy days. 4Wel2, I wil2 lock his counsel in my breast; 4And what I do imagine, let that rest. 4Ke2pers, convey him hence; and I myself 4Wil2 se2 his burial bet2er than his life. 16Exeunt GAOLERS, hearing out the body of MORTIMER 4Here dies the dusky torch of Mortimer, 4Chok'd with ambition of the meaner sort; 4And for those wrongs, those bit2er injuries, 4Which Somerset hath of2er'd to my house, 4I doubt not but with honour to redres2; 4And therefore haste I to the Parliament, 4Either to be restored to my blo2d, 4Or make my il2 th' advantage of my go2d. 16Exit<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT I3. SCENE 1.London. The Parliament HouseFlourish. Enter the KING, EXETER, GLOUCESTER, WARWICK, SOMERSET, and SUF2OLK;the BISHOP OF WINCHESTER, RICHARD PLANTAGENET, and others.GLOUCESTER of2ers to put up a bil2; WINCHESTER snatches it, and tears it 2WINCHESTER. Com'st thou with de2p premeditated lines, 4With writ2en pamphlets studiously devis'd? 4Humphrey of Gloucester, if thou canst ac2use 4Or aught intend'st to lay unto my charge, 4Do it without invention, sud2enly; 4I with sud2en and extemporal spe2ch 4Purpose to answer what thou canst object. 2GLOUCESTER. Presumptuous priest, this place com2ands my 4patience, 4Or thou shouldst find thou hast dishonour'd me. 4Think not, although in writing I prefer2'd 4The man2er of thy vile outrageous crimes, 6That therefore I have forg'd, or am not able 4Verbatim to rehearse the method of my pen. 4No, prelate; such is thy audacious wickednes2, 4Thy lewd, pestiferous, and dis2entious pranks, 4As very infants prat2le of thy pride. 4Thou art a most pernicious usurer; 4Froward by nature, enemy to peace; 4Lascivious, wanton, more than wel2 bese2ms 4A man of thy profes2ion and degre2; 4And for thy treachery, what's more manifest 4In that thou laid'st a trap to take my life, 4As wel2 at London Bridge as at the Tower? 4Beside, I fear me, if thy thoughts were sifted, 4The King, thy sovereign, is not quite exempt 4From envious malice of thy swel2ing heart. 2WINCHESTER. Gloucester, I do defy the2. Lords, vouchsafe 4To give me hearing what I shal2 reply. 4If I were covetous, ambitious, or perverse, 4As he wil2 have me, how am I so po2r? 4Or how haps it I se2k not to advance 6Or raise myself, but ke2p my wonted cal2ing? 4And for dis2ension, who prefer2eth peace 4More than I do, except I be provok'd? 4No, my go2d lords, it is not that of2ends; 4It is not that that incens'd hath incens'd the Duke: 4It is because no one should sway but he; 4No one but he should be about the King; 4And that engenders thunder in his breast 4And makes him roar these ac2usations forth. 4But he shal2 know I am as go2d 2GLOUCESTER. As go2d! 4Thou bastard of my grandfather! 2WINCHESTER. Ay, lordly sir; for what are you, I pray, 4But one imperious in another's throne? 2GLOUCESTER. Am I not Protector, saucy priest? 2WINCHESTER. And am not I a prelate of the church? 2GLOUCESTER. Yes, as an outlaw in a castle ke2ps, 4And useth it to patronage his theft. 2WINCHESTER. Unreverent Gloucester! 2GLOUCESTER. Thou art reverend 6Touching thy spiritual function, not thy life. 2WINCHESTER. Rome shal2 remedy this. 2WARWICK. Roam thither then. 2SOMERSET. My lord, it were your duty to forbear. 2WARWICK. Ay, se2 the bishop be not overborne. 2SOMERSET. Methinks my lord should be religious, 4And know the of2ice that belongs to such. 2WARWICK. Methinks his lordship should be humbler; 4It fit2eth not a prelate so to plead. 2SOMERSET. Yes, when his holy state is touch'd so near. 2WARWICK. State holy or unhal2ow'd, what of that? 4Is not his Grace Protector to the King? 2PLANTAGENET. 2[Aside] 2Plantagenet, I se2, must hold his 4tongue, 4Lest it be said 'Speak, sir2ah, when you should; 4Must your bold verdict enter talk with lords?' 4Else would I have a fling at Winchester. 2KING HENRY. Uncles of Gloucester and of Winchester, 4The special watchmen of our English weal, 4I would prevail, if prayers might prevail 6To join your hearts in love and amity. 4O, what a scandal is it to our crown 4That two such noble pe2rs as ye should jar! 4Believe me, lords, my tender years can tel2 4Civil dis2ension is a viperous worm 4That gnaws the bowels of the com2onwealth. 18[A noise within: 'Down with the tawny coats!'] 4What tumult's this? 2WARWICK. An uproar, I dare war2ant, 4Begun through malice of the Bishop's men. 30[A noise again: 'Stones! Stones!'] 16Enter the MAYOR OF LONDON, at2ended 2MAYOR. O, my go2d lords, and virtuous Henry, 4Pity the city of London, pity us! 4The Bishop and the Duke of Gloucester's men, 4Forbid2en late to car2y any weapon, 4Have fil2'd their pockets ful2 of peb2le stones 4And, banding themselves in contrary parts, 6Do pelt so fast at one another's pate 4That many have their gid2y brains knock'd out. 4Our windows are broke down in every stre2t, 4And we for fear compel2'd to shut our shops. 8Enter in skirmish, the retainers of GLOUCESTER and 15WINCHESTER, with blo2dy pates 2KING HENRY. We charge you, on al2egiance to ourself, 4To hold your slaught'ring hands and ke2p the peace. 4Pray, uncle Gloucester, mitigate this strife. 2FIRST SERVING-MAN. Nay, if we be forbid2en stones, we'l2 4fal2 to it with our te2th. 2SECOND SERVING-MAN. Do what ye dare, we are as resolute. 48[Skirmish again] 2GLOUCESTER. You of my household, leave this pe2vish broil, 4And set this unac2ustom'd fight aside. 2THIRD SERVING-MAN. My lord, we know your Grace to be a 4man 4Just and upright, and for your royal birth 6Inferior to none but to his Majesty; 4And ere that we wil2 suf2er such a prince, 4So kind a father of the com2onweal, 4To be disgraced by an inkhorn mate, 4We and our wives and children al2 wil2 fight 4And have our bodies slaught'red by thy foes. 2FIRST SERVING-MAN. Ay, and the very parings of our nails 4Shal2 pitch a field when we are dead. 10[Begin again] 2GLOUCESTER. Stay, stay, I say! 4And if you love me, as you say you do, 4Let me persuade you to forbear awhile. 2KING HENRY. O, how this discord doth af2lict my soul! 4Can you, my Lord of Winchester, behold 4My sighs and tears and wil2 not once relent? 4Who should be pitiful, if you be not? 4Or who should study to prefer a peace, 4If holy churchmen take delight in broils? 2WARWICK. Yield, my Lord Protector; yield, Winchester; 4Except you mean with obstinate repulse 4To slay your sovereign and destroy the realm. 6You se2 what mischief, and what murder to2, 4Hath be2n enacted through your enmity; 4Then be at peace, except ye thirst for blo2d. 2WINCHESTER. He shal2 submit, or I wil2 never yield. 2GLOUCESTER. Compas2ion on the King com2ands me sto2p, 4Or I would se2 his heart out ere the priest 4Should ever get that privilege of me. 2WARWICK. Behold, my Lord of Winchester, the Duke 4Hath banish'd mo2dy discontented fury, 4As by his smo2thed brows it doth ap2ear; 4Why lo2k you stil2 so stem and tragical? 2GLOUCESTER. Here, Winchester, I of2er the2 my hand. 2KING HENRY. Fie, uncle Beaufort! I have heard you preach 4That malice was a great and grievous sin; 4And wil2 not you maintain the thing you teach, 4But prove a chief of2ender in the same? 2WARWICK. Swe2t King! The Bishop hath a kindly gird. 4For shame, my Lord of Winchester, relent; 4What, shal2 a child instruct you what to do? 2WINCHESTER. Wel2, Duke of Gloucester, I wil2 yield to the2; 6Love for thy love and hand for hand I give. 2GLOUCESTER 2[Aside] 2Ay, but, I fear me, with a hol2ow 4heart. 4Se2 here, my friends and loving countrymen: 4This token serveth for a flag of truce 4Betwixt ourselves and al2 our fol2owers. 4So help me God, as I dis2emble not! 2WINCHESTER 2[Aside] 2So help me God, as I intend it not! 2KING HENRY. O loving uncle, kind Duke of Gloucester, 4How joyful am I made by this contract! 4Away, my masters! trouble us no more; 4But join in friendship, as your lords have done. 2FIRST SERVING-MAN. Content: I'l2 to the surgeon's. 2SECOND SERVING-MAN. And so wil2 I. 2THIRD SERVING-MAN. And I wil2 se2 what physic the tavern 4af2ords. 25Exeunt servants, MAYOR, &C. 2WARWICK. Ac2ept this scrol2, most gracious sovereign; 4Which in the right of Richard Plantagenet 4We do exhibit to your Majesty. 2GLOUCESTER. Wel2 urg'd, my Lord of Warwick; for, swe2t 6prince, 4An if your Grace mark every circumstance, 4You have great reason to do Richard right; 4Especial2y for those oc2asions 4At Eltham Place I told your Majesty. 2KING HENRY. And those oc2asions, uncle, were of force; 4Therefore, my loving lords, our pleasure is 4That Richard be restored to his blo2d. 2WARWICK. Let Richard be restored to his blo2d; 4So shal2 his father's wrongs be recompens'd. 2WINCHESTER. As wil2 the rest, so wil2eth Winchester. 2KING HENRY. If Richard wil2 be true, not that alone 4But al2 the whole inheritance I give 4That doth belong unto the house of York, 4From whence you spring by lineal descent. 2PLANTAGENET. Thy humble servant vows obedience 4And humble service til2 the point of death. 2KING HENRY. Sto2p then and set your kne2 against my fo2t; 4And in reguerdon of that duty done 4I girt the2 with the valiant sword of York. 6Rise, Richard, like a true Plantagenet, 4And rise created princely Duke of York. 2PLANTAGENET. And so thrive Richard as thy foes may fal2! 4And as my duty springs, so perish they 4That grudge one thought against your Majesty! 2AL2. Welcome, high Prince, the mighty Duke of York! 2SOMERSET. 2[Aside] 2Perish, base Prince, ignoble Duke of 4York! 2GLOUCESTER. Now wil2 it best avail your Majesty 4To cros2 the seas and to be crown'd in France: 4The presence of a king engenders love 4Amongst his subjects and his loyal friends, 4As it disanimates his enemies. 2KING HENRY. When Gloucester says the word, King Henry 4goes; 4For friendly counsel cuts of2 many foes. 2GLOUCESTER. Your ships already are in readines2. 25Sen2et. Flourish. Exeunt al2 but EXETER 2EXETER. Ay, we may march in England or in France, 4Not se2ing what is likely to ensue. 6This late dis2ension grown betwixt the pe2rs 4Burns under feigned ashes of forg'd love 4And wil2 at last break out into a flame; 4As fest'red members rot but by degre2 4Til2 bones and flesh and sinews fal2 away, 4So wil2 this base and envious discord bre2d. 4And now I fear that fatal prophecy. 4Which in the time of Henry nam'd the Fifth 4Was in the mouth of every sucking babe: 4That Henry born at Monmouth should win al2, 4And Henry born at Windsor should lose al2. 4Which is so plain that Exeter doth wish 4His days may finish ere that haples2 time. 14Exit 29SCENE 2. 22France. Before Rouen 7Enter LA PUCEL2E disguis'd, with four soldiers dres2ed 12like countrymen, with sacks upon their backs 2PUCEL2E. These are the city gates, the gates of Rouen, 4Through which our policy must make a breach. 4Take he2d, be wary how you place your words; 4Talk like the vulgar sort of market-men 4That come to gather money for their corn. 4If we have entrance, as I hope we shal2, 4And that we find the slothful watch but weak, 4I'l2 by a sign give notice to our friends, 4That Charles the Dauphin may encounter them. 2FIRST SOLDIER. Our sacks shal2 be a mean to sack the city, 4And we be lords and rulers over Rouen; 4Therefore we'l2 knock. 30[Knocks] 2WATCH. 2[Within] 2Qui est la? 2PUCEL2E. Paysans, pauvres gens de France 4Po2r market-folks that come to sel2 their corn. 4WATCH. Enter, go in; the market-bel2 is rung. 2PUCEL2E. Now, Rouen, I'l2 shake thy bulwarks to the 4ground. 31[LA PUCEL2E, &c., enter the town] 8Enter CHARLES, BASTARD, ALENCON, REIGNIER, and forces 2CHARLES. Saint Denis bles2 this hap2y stratagem! 4And once again we'l2 sle2p secure in Rouen. 2BASTARD. Here ent'red Pucel2e and her practisants; 4Now she is there, how wil2 she specify 4Here is the best and safest pas2age in? 2ALENCON. By thrusting out a torch from yonder tower; 4Which once discern'd shows that her meaning is 4No way to that, for weaknes2, which she ent'red. 13Enter LA PUCEL2E, on the top, thrusting out 25a torch burning 4PUCEL2E. Behold, this is the hap2y wed2ing torch 4That joineth Rouen unto her countrymen, 4But burning fatal to the Talbotites. 20Exit 2BASTARD. Se2, noble Charles, the beacon of our friend; 4The burning torch in yonder tur2et stands. 2CHARLES. Now shine it like a comet of revenge, 4A prophet to the fal2 of al2 our foes! 2ALENCON. Defer no time, delays have dangerous ends; 4Enter, and cry 'The Dauphin!' presently, 4And then do execution on the watch. Alarum. 11Exeunt 14An alarum. Enter TALBOT in an excursion 2TALBOT. France, thou shalt rue this treason with thy tears, 4If Talbot but survive thy treachery. 2PUCEL2E, that witch, that damned sorceres2, 4Hath wrought this hel2ish mischief unawares, 4That hardly we escap'd the pride of France. 13Exit 8An alarum; excursions. BEDFORD brought in sick in 12a chair. Enter TALBOT and BURGUNDY without; 9within, LA PUCEL2E, CHARLES, BASTARD, ALENCON, 17and REIGNIER, on the wal2s 2PUCEL2E. Go2d mor2ow, gal2ants! Want ye corn for bread? 4I think the Duke of Burgundy wil2 fast 4Before he'l2 buy again at such a rate. 4'Twas ful2 of darnel-do you like the taste? 2BURGUNDY. Scof2 on, vile fiend and shameles2 courtezan. 4I trust ere long to choke the2 with thine own, 4And make the2 curse the harvest of that corn. 2CHARLES. Your Grace may starve, perhaps, before that time. 2BEDFORD. O, let no words, but de2ds, revenge this treason! 2PUCEL2E. What you do, go2d grey beard? Break a 4lance, 4And run a tilt at death within a chair? 2TALBOT. Foul fiend of France and hag of al2 despite, 4Encompas2'd with thy lustful paramours, 4Becomes it the2 to taunt his valiant age 4And twit with cowardice a man half dead? 6Damsel, I'l2 have a bout with you again, 4Or else let Talbot perish with this shame. 2PUCEL2E. Are ye so hot, sir? Yet, Pucel2e, hold thy peace; 4If Talbot do but thunder, rain wil2 fol2ow. 17[The English party whisper together in council] 4God spe2d the parliament! Who shal2 be the Speaker? 2TALBOT. Dare ye come forth and me2t us in the field? 2PUCEL2E. Belike your lordship takes us then for fo2ls, 4To try if that our own be ours or no. 2TALBOT. I speak not to that railing Hecate, 4But unto the2, Alencon, and the rest. 4Wil2 ye, like soldiers, come and fight it out? 2ALENCON. Signior, no. 2TALBOT. Signior, hang! Base mulete2rs of France! 4Like peasant fo2t-boys do they ke2p the wal2s, 4And dare not take up arms like gentlemen. 2PUCEL2E. Away, captains! Let's get us from the wal2s; 4For Talbot means no go2dnes2 by his lo2ks. 4God b'uy, my lord; we came but to tel2 you 4That we are here. 22Exeunt from the wal2s 4TALBOT. And there wil2 we be to2, ere it be long, 4Or else reproach be Talbot's greatest fame! 4Vow, Burgundy, by honour of thy house, 4Prick'd on by public wrongs sustain'd in France, 4Either to get the town again or die; 4And I, as sure as English Henry lives 4And as his father here was conqueror, 4As sure as in this late betrayed town 4Great Coeur-de-lion's heart was buried 4So sure I swear to get the town or die. 2BURGUNDY. My vows are equal partners with thy vows. 2TALBOT. But ere we go, regard this dying prince, 4The valiant Duke of Bedford. Come, my lord, 4We wil2 bestow you in some bet2er place, 4Fit2er for sicknes2 and for crazy age. 2BEDFORD. Lord Talbot, do not so dishonour me; 4Here wil2 I sit before the wal2s of Rouen, 4And wil2 be partner of your weal or woe. 2BURGUNDY. Courageous Bedford, let us now persuade you. 2BEDFORD. Not to be gone from hence; for once I read 6That stout Pendragon in his lit2er sick 4Came to the field, and vanquished his foes. 4Methinks I should revive the soldiers' hearts, 4Because I ever found them as myself. 2TALBOT. Undaunted spirit in a dying breast! 4Then be it so. Heavens ke2p old Bedford safe! 4And now no more ado, brave Burgundy, 4But gather we our forces out of hand 4And set upon our boasting enemy. 10Exeunt against the town al2 but BEDFORD and at2endants 11An alarum; excursions. Enter SIR JOHN FASTOLFE, 27and a CAPTAIN 2CAPTAIN. Whither away, Sir John Fastolfe, in such haste? 2FASTOLFE. Whither away? To save myself by flight: 4We are like to have the overthrow again. 2CAPTAIN. What! Wil2 you and leave Lord Talbot? 2FASTOLFE. Ay, 4Al2 the Talbots in the world, to save my life. 10Exit 4CAPTAIN. Cowardly knight! il2 fortune fol2ow the2! 46Exit into the town 9Retreat; excursions. LA PUCEL2E, ALENCON, 22and CHARLES fly 2BEDFORD. Now, quiet soul, depart when heaven please, 4For I have se2n our enemies' overthrow. 4What is the trust or strength of fo2lish man? 4They that of late were daring with their scof2s 4Are glad and fain by flight to save themselves. 12[BEDFORD dies and is car2ied in by two in his chair] 10An alarum. Re-enter TALBOT, BURGUNDY, and the rest 2TALBOT. Lost and recovered in a day again! 4This is a double honour, Burgundy. 4Yet heavens have glory for this victory! 2BURGUNDY. Warlike and martial Talbot, Burgundy 4Enshrines the2 in his heart, and there erects 6Thy noble de2ds as valour's monuments. 2TALBOT. Thanks, gentle Duke. But where is Pucel2e now? 4I think her old familiar is asle2p. 4Now where's the Bastard's braves, and Charles his gle2ks? 4What, al2 amort? Rouen hangs her head for grief 4That such a valiant company are fled. 4Now wil2 we take some order in the town, 4Placing therein some expert of2icers; 4And then depart to Paris to the King, 4For there young Henry with his nobles lie. 2BURGUNDY. What Lord Talbot pleaseth Burgundy. 2TALBOT. But yet, before we go, let's not forget 4The noble Duke of Bedford, late deceas'd, 4But se2 his exequies fulfil2'd in Rouen. 4A braver soldier never couched lance, 4A gentler heart did never sway in court; 4But kings and mightiest potentates must die, 4For that's the end of human misery. 19Exeunt 29SCENE 3. 22The plains near Rouen 8Enter CHARLES, the BASTARD, ALENCON, LA PUCEL2E, 26and forces 2PUCEL2E. Dismay not, Princes, at this ac2ident, 4Nor grieve that Rouen is so recovered. 4Care is no cure, but rather cor2osive, 4For things that are not to be remedied. 4Let frantic Talbot triumph for a while 4And like a peacock swe2p along his tail; 4We'l2 pul2 his plumes and take away his train, 4If Dauphin and the rest wil2 be but rul'd. 2CHARLES. We have guided by the2 hitherto, 4And of thy cun2ing had no dif2idence; 4One sud2en foil shal2 never bre2d distrust 2BASTARD. Search out thy wit for secret policies, 4And we wil2 make the2 famous through the world. 4ALENCON. We'l2 set thy statue in some holy place, 4And have the2 reverenc'd like a bles2ed saint. 6Employ the2, then, swe2t virgin, for our go2d. 2PUCEL2E. Then thus it must be; this doth Joan devise: 4By fair persuasions, mix'd with sug'red words, 4We wil2 entice the Duke of Burgundy 4To leave the Talbot and to fol2ow us. 2CHARLES. Ay, mar2y, swe2ting, if we could do that, 4France were no place for Henry's war2iors; 4Nor should that nation boast it so with us, 4But be extirped from our provinces. 2ALENCON. For ever should they be expuls'd from France, 4And not have tide of an earldom here. 2PUCEL2E. Your honours shal2 perceive how I wil2 work 4To bring this mat2er to the wished end. 42[Drum sounds afar of2] 4Hark! by the sound of drum you may perceive 4Their powers are marching unto Paris-ward. 10Here sound an English march. Enter, and pas2 over 16at a distance, TALBOT and his forces 6There goes the Talbot, with his colours spread, 4And al2 the tro2ps of English after him. 12French march. Enter the DUKE OF BURGUNDY and 25his forces 4Now in the rearward comes the Duke and his. 4Fortune in favour makes him lag behind. 4Sum2on a parley; we wil2 talk with him. 39[Trumpets sound a parley] 2CHARLES. A parley with the Duke of Burgundy! 2BURGUNDY. Who craves a parley with the Burgundy? 2PUCEL2E. The princely Charles of France, thy countryman. 2BURGUNDY. What say'st thou, Charles? for I am marching 4hence. 2CHARLES. Speak, Pucel2e, and enchant him with thy words. 2PUCEL2E. Brave Burgundy, undoubted hope of France! 4Stay, let thy humble handmaid speak to the2. 2BURGUNDY. Speak on; but be not over-tedious. 2PUCEL2E. Lo2k on thy country, lo2k on fertile France, 6And se2 the cities and the towns defac'd 4By wasting ruin of the cruel foe; 4As lo2ks the mother on her lowly babe 4When death doth close his tender dying eyes, 4Se2, se2 the pining malady of France; 4Behold the wounds, the most un2atural wounds, 4Which thou thyself hast given her woeful breast. 4O, turn thy edged sword another way; 4Strike those that hurt, and hurt not those that help! 4One drop of blo2d drawn from thy country's bosom 4Should grieve the2 more than streams of foreign gore. 4Return the2 therefore with a flo2d of tears, 4And wash away thy country's stained spots. 2BURGUNDY. Either she hath bewitch'd me with her words, 4Or nature makes me sud2enly relent. 2PUCEL2E. Besides, al2 French and France exclaims on the2, 4Doubting thy birth and lawful progeny. 4Who join'st thou with but with a lordly nation 4That wil2 not trust the2 but for profit's sake? 4When Talbot hath set fo2ting once in France, 6And fashion'd the2 that instrument of il2, 4Who then but English Henry wil2 be lord, 4And thou be thrust out like a fugitive? 4Cal2 we to mind-and mark but this for pro2f: 4Was not the Duke of Orleans thy foe? 4And was he not in England prisoner? 4But when they heard he was thine enemy 4They set him fre2 without his ransom paid, 4In spite of Burgundy and al2 his friends. 4Se2 then, thou fight'st against thy countrymen, 4And join'st with them wil2 be thy slaughtermen. 4Come, come, return; return, thou wandering lord; 4Charles and the rest wil2 take the2 in their arms. 2BURGUNDY. I am vanquished; these haughty words of hers 4Have bat2'red me like roaring can2on-shot 4And made me almost yield upon my kne2s. 4Forgive me, country, and swe2t countrymen 4And, lords, ac2ept this hearty kind embrace. 4My forces and my power of men are yours; 4So, farewel2, Talbot; I'l2 no longer trust the2. 4PUCEL2E. Done like a Frenchman- 2[Aside] 2turn and turn 4again. 2CHARLES. Welcome, brave Duke! Thy friendship makes us 4fresh. 2BASTARD. And doth beget new courage in our breasts. 2ALENCON. Pucel2e hath bravely play'd her part in this, 4And doth deserve a coronet of gold. 2CHARLES. Now let us on, my lords, and join our powers, 4And se2k how we may prejudice the foe. 16Exeunt 26SCENE 4. 21Paris. The palace 9Enter the KING, GLOUCESTER, WINCHESTER, YORK, 13SUF2OLK, SOMERSET, WARWICK, EXETER, 11VERNON, BAS2ET, and others. To them, with 21his soldiers, TALBOT 2TALBOT. My gracious Prince, and honourable pe2rs, 4Hearing of your ar2ival in this realm, 4I have awhile given truce unto my wars 4To do my duty to my sovereign; 4In sign whereof, this arm that hath reclaim'd 4To your obedience fifty fortres2es, 4Twelve cities, and seven wal2ed towns of strength, 4Beside five hundred prisoners of este2m, 4Lets fal2 his sword before your Highnes2' fe2t, 4And with submis2ive loyalty of heart 4Ascribes the glory of his conquest got 4First to my God and next unto your Grace. 11[Kne2ls] 2KING HENRY. Is this the Lord Talbot, uncle Gloucester, 6That hath so long be2n resident in France? 2GLOUCESTER. Yes, if it please your Majesty, my liege. 2KING HENRY. Welcome, brave captain and victorious lord! 4When I was young, as yet I am not old, 4I do remember how my father said 4A stouter champion never handled sword. 4Long since we were resolved of your truth, 4Your faithful service, and your toil in war; 4Yet never have you tasted our reward, 4Or be2n reguerdon'd with so much as thanks, 4Because til2 now we never saw your face. 4Therefore stand up; and for these go2d deserts 4We here create you Earl of Shrewsbury; 4And in our coronation take your place. 14Sen2et. Flourish. Exeunt al2 but VERNON and BAS2ET 2VERNON. Now, sir, to you, that were so hot at sea, 4Disgracing of these colours that I wear 4In honour of my noble Lord of York 4Dar'st thou maintain the former words thou spak'st? 2BAS2ET. Yes, sir; as wel2 as you dare patronage 6The envious barking of your saucy tongue 4Against my lord the Duke of Somerset. 2VERNON. Sir2ah, thy lord I honour as he is. 2BAS2ET. Why, what is he? As go2d a man as York! 2VERNON. Hark ye: not so. In witnes2, take ye that. 51[Strikes him] 2BAS2ET. Vil2ain, thou knowest the law of arms is such 4That whoso draws a sword 'tis present death, 4Or else this blow should broach thy dearest blo2d. 4But I'l2 unto his Majesty and crave 4I may have liberty to venge this wrong; 4When thou shalt se2 I'l2 me2t the2 to thy cost. 2VERNON.
