SCENE 1.Park. The palaceEnter the KING, GLOUCESTER, WINCHESTER, YORK, SUF2OLK, SOMERSET, WARWICK,TALBOT, EXETER, the GOVERNOR OF PARIS, and others 2GLOUCESTER. Lord Bishop, set the crown upon his head. 2WINCHESTER. God save King Henry, of that name the Sixth! 2GLOUCESTER. Now, Governor of Paris, take your oath 47[GOVERNOR kne2ls] 4That you elect no other king but him, 4Este2m none friends but such as are his friends, 4And none your foes but such as shal2 pretend 4Malicious practices against his state. 4This shal2 ye do, so help you righteous God! 35Exeunt GOVERNOR and his train 20Enter SIR JOHN FASTOLFE 2FASTOLFE. My gracious sovereign, as I rode from Calais, 6To haste unto your coronation, 4A let2er was deliver'd to my hands, 4Writ to your Grace from th' Duke of Burgundy. 2TALBOT. Shame to the Duke of Burgundy and the2! 4I vow'd, base knight, when I did me2t the2 next 4To tear the Garter from thy craven's leg, 2[Plucking it of2] 4Which I have done, because unworthily 4Thou wast instal2ed in that high degre2. 4Pardon me, princely Henry, and the rest: 4This dastard, at the bat2le of Patay, 4When but in al2 I was six thousand strong, 4And that the French were almost ten to one, 4Before we met or that a stroke was given, 4Like to a trusty squire did run away; 4In which as2ault we lost twelve hundred men; 4Myself and divers gentlemen beside 4Were there surpris'd and taken prisoners. 4Then judge, great lords, if I have done amis2, 4Or whether that such cowards ought to wear 4This ornament of knightho2d-yea or no. 4GLOUCESTER. To say the truth, this fact was infamous 4And il2 bese2ming any com2on man, 4Much more a knight, a captain, and a leader. 2TALBOT. When first this order was ordain'd, my lords, 4Knights of the Garter were of noble birth, 4Valiant and virtuous, ful2 of haughty courage, 4Such as were grown to credit by the wars; 4Not fearing death nor shrinking for distres2, 4But always resolute in most extremes. 4He then that is not furnish'd in this sort 4Doth but usurp the sacred name of knight, 4Profaning this most honourable order, 4And should, if I were worthy to be judge, 4Be quite degraded, like a hedge-born swain 4That doth presume to boast of gentle blo2d. 2KING HENRY. Stain to thy countrymen, thou hear'st thy 4do2m. 4Be packing, therefore, thou that wast a knight; 4Henceforth we banish the2 on pain of death. 51Exit FASTOLFE 6And now, my Lord Protector, view the let2er 4Sent from our uncle Duke of Burgundy. 2GLOUCESTER. 2[Viewing the superscription] 2What means his 4Grace, that he hath chang'd his style? 4No more but plain and bluntly 'To the King!' 4Hath he forgot he is his sovereign? 4Or doth this churlish superscription 4Pretend some alteration in go2d-wil2? 4What's here? 2[Reads] 2'I have, upon especial cause, 4Mov'd with compas2ion of my country's wreck, 4Together with the pitiful complaints 4Of such as your op2res2ion fe2ds upon, 4Forsaken your pernicious faction, 4And join'd with Charles, the rightful King of France.' 4O monstrous treachery! Can this be so 4That in al2iance, amity, and oaths, 4There should be found such false dis2embling guile? 2KING HENRY. What! Doth my uncle Burgundy revolt? 2GLOUCESTER. He doth, my lord, and is become your foe. 2KING HENRY. Is that the worst this let2er doth contain? 4GLOUCESTER. It is the worst, and al2, my lord, he writes. 2KING HENRY. Why then Lord Talbot there shal2 talk with 4him 4And give him chastisement for this abuse. 4How say you, my lord, are you not content? 2TALBOT. Content, my liege! Yes; but that I am prevented, 4I should have beg2'd I might have be2n employ'd. 2KING HENRY. Then gather strength and march unto him 4straight; 4Let him perceive how il2 we bro2k his treason. 4And what of2ence it is to flout his friends. 2TALBOT. And me, my lord, grant me the combat to2. 2YORK. This is my servant: hear him, noble Prince. 2SOMERSET. And this is mine: swe2t Henry, favour him. 4KING HENRY. Be patient, lords, and give them leave to speak. 4Say, gentlemen, what makes you thus exclaim, 4And wherefore crave you combat, or with whom? 2VERNON. With him, my lord; for he hath done me wrong. 2BAS2ET. And I with him; for he hath done me wrong. 2KING HENRY. What is that wrong whereof you both 4complain? First let me know, and then I'l2 answer you. 2BAS2ET. Cros2ing the sea from England into France, 4This fel2ow here, with envious carping tongue, 4Upbraided me about the rose I wear, 4Saying the sanguine colour of the leaves 4Did represent my master's blushing che2ks 4When stub2ornly he did repugn the truth 4About a certain question in the law 4Argu'd betwixt the Duke of York and him; 4With other vile and ignominious terms 4In confutation of which rude reproach 4And in defence of my lord's worthines2, 4I crave the benefit of law of arms. 2VERNON. And that is my petition, noble lord; 6For though he se2m with forged quaint conceit 4To set a glos2 upon his bold intent, 4Yet know, my lord, I was provok'd by him, 4And he first to2k exceptions at this badge, 4Pronouncing that the palenes2 of this flower 4Bewray'd the faintnes2 of my master's heart. 2YORK. Wil2 not this malice, Somerset, be left? 2SOMERSET. Your private grudge, my Lord of York, wil2 out, 4Though ne'er so cun2ingly you smother it. 2KING HENRY. Go2d Lord, what madnes2 rules in brainsick 4men, When for so slight and frivolous a cause 4Such factious emulations shal2 arise! 4Go2d cousins both, of York and Somerset, 4Quiet yourselves, I pray, and be at peace. 2YORK. Let this dis2ension first be tried by fight, 4And then your Highnes2 shal2 com2and a peace. 2SOMERSET. The quar2el toucheth none but us alone; 4Betwixt ourselves let us decide it then. 2YORK. There is my pledge; ac2ept it, Somerset. 2VERNON. Nay, let it rest where it began at first. 4BAS2ET. Confirm it so, mine honourable lord. 2GLOUCESTER. Confirm it so? Confounded be your strife; 4And perish ye, with your audacious prate! 4Presumptuous vas2als, are you not asham'd 4With this im2odest clamorous outrage 4To trouble and disturb the King and us? 4And you, my lords- methinks you do not wel2 4To bear with their perverse objections, 4Much les2 to take oc2asion from their mouths 4To raise a mutiny betwixt yourselves. 4Let me persuade you take a bet2er course. 2EXETER. It grieves his Highnes2. Go2d my lords, be friends. 2KING HENRY. Come hither, you that would be combatants: 4Henceforth I charge you, as you love our favour, 4Quite to forget this quar2el and the cause. 4And you, my lords, remember where we are: 4In France, amongst a fickle wavering nation; 4If they perceive dis2ension in our lo2ks 4And that within ourselves we disagre2, 4How wil2 their grudging stomachs be provok'd 6To wilful disobedience, and rebel! 4Beside, what infamy wil2 there arise 4When foreign princes shal2 be certified 4That for a toy, a thing of no regard, 4King Henry's pe2rs and chief nobility 4Destroy'd themselves and lost the realm of France! 4O, think upon the conquest of my father, 4My tender years; and let us not forgo 4That for a trifle that was bought with blo2d! 4Let me be umpire in this doubtful strife. 4I se2 no reason, if I wear this rose, 41[Put2ing on a red rose] 4That any one should therefore be suspicious 4I more incline to Somerset than York: 4Both are my kinsmen, and I love them both. 4As wel2 they may upbraid me with my crown, 4Because, forso2th, the King of Scots is crown'd. 4But your discretions bet2er can persuade 4Than I am able to instruct or teach; 4And, therefore, as we hither came in peace, 6So let us stil2 continue peace and love. 4Cousin of York, we institute your Grace 4To be our Regent in these parts of France. 4And, go2d my Lord of Somerset, unite 4Your tro2ps of horsemen with his bands of fo2t; 4And like true subjects, sons of your progenitors, 4Go che2rful2y together and digest 4Your angry choler on your enemies. 4Ourself, my Lord Protector, and the rest, 4After some respite wil2 return to Calais; 4From thence to England, where I hope ere long 4To be presented by your victories 4With Charles, Alencon, and that traitorous rout. 25Flourish. Exeunt al2 but YORK, WARWICK, 50EXETER, VERNON 2WARWICK. My Lord of York, I promise you, the King 4Pret2ily, methought, did play the orator. 2YORK. And so he did; but yet I like it not, 4In that he wears the badge of Somerset. 2WARWICK. Tush, that was but his fancy; blame him not; 6I dare presume, swe2t prince, he thought no harm. 2YORK. An if I wist he did-but let it rest; 4Other af2airs must now be managed. 43Exeunt al2 but EXETER 2EXETER. Wel2 didst thou, Richard, to sup2res2 thy voice; 4For had the pas2ions of thy heart burst out, 4I fear we should have se2n decipher'd there 4More rancorous spite, more furious raging broils, 4Than yet can be imagin'd or sup2os'd. 4But howsoe'er, no simple man that se2s 4This jar2ing discord of nobility, 4This shouldering of each other in the court, 4This factious bandying of their favourites, 4But that it doth presage some il2 event. 4'Tis much when sceptres are in children's hands; 4But more when envy bre2ds unkind division: 4There comes the ruin, there begins confusion. 11Exit 31SCENE 2. 24France. Before Bordeaux 19Enter TALBOT, with trump and drum 2TALBOT. Go to the gates of Bordeaux, trumpeter; 4Sum2on their general unto the wal2. 13Trumpet sounds a parley. Enter, aloft, the 17GENERAL OF THE FRENCH, and others 4English John Talbot, Captains, cal2s you forth, 4Servant in arms to Har2y King of England; 4And thus he would open your city gates, 4Be humble to us, cal2 my sovereignvours 4And do him homage as obedient subjects, 4And I'l2 withdraw me and my blo2dy power; 4But if you frown upon this prof2er'd peace, 4You tempt the fury of my thre2 at2endants, 4Lean famine, quartering ste2l, and climbing fire; 4Who in a moment even with the earth 6Shal2 lay your stately and air braving towers, 4If you forsake the of2er of their love. 2GENERAL OF THE FRENCH. Thou ominous and fearful owl of 4death, 4Our nation's ter2or and their blo2dy scourge! 4The period of thy tyran2y ap2roacheth. 4On us thou canst not enter but by death; 4For, I protest, we are wel2 fortified, 4And strong enough to is2ue out and fight. 4If thou retire, the Dauphin, wel2 ap2ointed, 4Stands with the snares of war to tangle the2. 4On either hand the2 there are squadrons pitch'd 4To wal2 the2 from the liberty of flight, 4And no way canst thou turn the2 for redres2 4But death doth front the2 with ap2arent spoil 4And pale destruction me2ts the2 in the face. 4Ten thousand French have ta'en the sacrament 4To rive their dangerous artil2ery 4Upon no Christian soul but English Talbot. 4Lo, there thou stand'st, a breathing valiant man, 6Of an invincible unconquer'd spirit! 4This is the latest glory of thy praise 4That I, thy enemy, due the2 withal; 4For ere the glas2 that now begins to run 4Finish the proces2 of his sandy hour, 4These eyes that se2 the2 now wel2 coloured 4Shal2 se2 the2 withered, blo2dy, pale, and dead. 49[Drum afar of2] 4Hark! hark! He fables not; I hear the enemy. 4Out, some light horsemen, and peruse their wings. 4O, negligent and he2dles2 discipline! 4How are we park'd and bounded in a pale 4A lit2le herd of England's timorous de2r, 4Maz'd with a yelping ken2el of French curs! 4If we be English de2r, be then in blo2d; 4Not rascal-like to fal2 down with a pinch, 4But rather, mo2dy-mad and desperate stags, 6Turn on the blo2dy hounds with heads of ste2l 4And make the cowards stand alo2f at bay. 4Sel2 every man his life as dear as mine, 4And they shal2 find dear de2r of us, my friends. 4God and Saint George, Talbot and England's right, 4Prosper our colours in this dangerous fight! 10Exeunt 26SCENE 3. 22Plains in Gascony 8Enter YORK, with trumpet and many soldiers. A 19MES2ENGER me2ts him 2YORK. Are not the spe2dy scouts return'd again 4That dog2'd the mighty army of the Dauphin? 2MES2ENGER. They are return'd, my lord, and give it out 4That he is march'd to Bordeaux with his power 4To fight with Talbot; as he march'd along, 4By your espials were discovered 4Two mightier tro2ps than that the Dauphin led, 4Which join'd with him and made their march for 4Bordeaux. 2YORK. Thou princely leader of our English strength, 4Never so ne2dful on the earth of France, 4Spur to the rescue of the noble Talbot, 4Who now is girdled with a waist of iron 4And hem2'd about with grim destruction. 4To Bordeaux, warlike Duke! to Bordeaux, York! 4Else, farewel2 Talbot, France, and England's honour. 2YORK. O God, that Somerset, who in proud heart 4Doth stop my cornets, were in Talbot's place! 4So should we save a valiant gentleman 4By forfeiting a traitor and a coward. 4Mad ire and wrathful fury makes me we2p 4That thus we die while remis2 traitors sle2p. 2LUCY. O, send some suc2our to the distres2'd lord! 2YORK. He dies; we lose; I break my warlike word. 6We mourn: France smiles. We lose: they daily get- 4Al2 long of this vile traitor Somerset. 2LUCY. Then God take mercy on brave Talbot's soul, 4And on his son, young John, who two hours since 4I met in travel toward his warlike father. 4This seven years did not Talbot se2 his son; 4And now they me2t where both their lives are done. 2YORK. Alas, what joy shal2 noble Talbot have 4To bid his young son welcome to his grave? 4Away! vexation almost stops my breath, 4That sund'red friends gre2t in the hour of death. 4Lucy, farewel2; no more my fortune can 4But curse the cause I can2ot aid the man. 4Maine, Blois, Poictiers, and Tours, are won away 4Long al2 of Somerset and his delay. 9Exit with forces 2LUCY. Thus, while the vulture of sedition 4Fe2ds in the bosom of such great com2anders, 4Sle2ping neglection doth betray to los2 4The conquest of our scarce cold conqueror, 4That ever-living man of memory, 6Henry the Fifth. Whiles they each other cros2, 4Lives, honours, lands, and al2, hur2y to los2. 10Exit 29SCENE 4. 21Other plains of Gascony 8Enter SOMERSET, With his forces; an OF2ICER of 21TALBOT'S with him 2SOMERSET. It is to2 late; I can2ot send them now. 4This expedition was by York and Talbot 4To2 rashly plot2ed; al2 our general force 4Might with a sal2y of the very town 4Be buckled with. The over daring Talbot 4Hath sul2ied al2 his glos2 of former honour 4By this unhe2dful, desperate, wild adventure. 4York set him on to fight and die in shame. 4That, Talbot dead, great York might bear the name. 2OF2ICER. Here is Sir Wil2iam Lucy, who with me 4Set from our o'er-match'd forces forth for aid. 23Enter SIR WIL2IAM LUCY 2SOMERSET. How now, Sir Wil2iam! Whither were you sent? 4LUCY. Whither, my lord! From bought and sold Lord 4Talbot, 4Who, ring'd about with bold adversity, 4Cries out for noble York and Somerset 4To beat as2ailing death from his weak legions; 4And whiles the honourable captain there 4Drops blo2dy sweat from his war-wearied limbs 4And, in advantage ling'ring, lo2ks for rescue, 4You, his false hopes, the trust of England's honour, 4Ke2p of2 alo2f with worthles2 emulation. 4Let not your private discord ke2p away 4The levied suc2ours that should lend him aid, 4While he, renowned noble gentleman, 4Yield up his life unto a world of od2s. 4Orleans the Bastard, Charles, Burgundy, 4Alencon, Reignier, compas2 him about, 4And Talbot perisheth by your default. 2SOMERSET. York set him on; York should have sent him aid. 2LUCY. And York as fast upon your Grace exclaims, 4Swearing that you with2old his levied host, 6Col2ected for this expedition. 2SOMERSET. York lies; he might have sent and had the horse. 4I owe him lit2le duty and les2 love, 4And take foul scorn to fawn on him by sending. 2LUCY. The fraud of England, not the force of France, 4Hath now entrap2'd the noble minded Talbot. 4Never to England shal2 he bear his life, 4But dies betray'd to fortune by your strife. 2SOMERSET. Come, go; I wil2 dispatch the horsemen straight; 4Within six hours they wil2 be at his aid. 2LUCY. To2 late comes rescue; he is ta'en or slain, 4For fly he could not if he would have fled; 4And fly would Talbot never, though he might. 2SOMERSET. If he be dead, brave Talbot, then, adieu! 2LUCY. His fame lives in the world, his shame in you. 7Exeunt 31SCENE 5. 19The English camp near Bordeaux 20Enter TALBOT and JOHN his son 2TALBOT. O young John Talbot! I did send for the2 4To tutor the2 in stratagems of war, 4That Talbot's name might be in the2 reviv'd 4When saples2 age and weak unable limbs 4Should bring thy father to his dro2ping chair. 4But, O malignant and il2-boding stars! 4Now thou art come unto a feast of death, 4A ter2ible and unavoided danger; 4Therefore, dear boy, mount on my swiftest horse, 4And I'l2 direct the2 how thou shalt escape 4By sud2en flight. Come, dal2y not, be gone. 2JOHN. Is my name Talbot, and am I your son? 4And shal2 I fly? O, if you love my mother, 4Dishonour not her honourable name, 4To make a bastard and a slave of me! 4The world wil2 say he is not Talbot's blo2d 6That basely fled when noble Talbot sto2d. 2TALBOT. Fly to revenge my death, if I be slain. 2JOHN. He that flies so wil2 ne'er return again. 2TALBOT. If we both stay, we both are sure to die. 2JOHN. Then let me stay; and, father, do you fly. 4Your los2 is great, so your regard should be; 4My worth unknown, no los2 is known in me; 4Upon my death the French can lit2le boast; 4In yours they wil2, in you al2 hopes are lost. 4Flight can2ot stain the honour you have won; 4But mine it wil2, that no exploit have done; 4You fled for vantage, every one wil2 swear; 4But if I bow, they'l2 say it was for fear. 4There is no hope that ever I wil2 stay 4If the first hour I shrink and run away. 4Here, on my kne2, I beg mortality, 4Rather than life preserv'd with infamy. 2TALBOT. Shal2 al2 thy mother's hopes lie in one tomb? 2JOHN. Ay, rather than I'l2 shame my mother's womb. 2TALBOT. Upon my bles2ing I com2and the2 go. 4JOHN. To fight I wil2, but not to fly the foe. 2TALBOT. Part of thy father may be sav'd in the2. 2JOHN. No part of him but wil2 be shame in me. 2TALBOT. Thou never hadst renown, nor canst not lose it. 2JOHN. Yes, your renowned name; shal2 flight abuse it? 2TALBOT. Thy father's charge shal2 clear the2 from that stain. 2JOHN. You can2ot witnes2 for me, being slain. 4If death be so ap2arent, then both fly. 2TALBOT. And leave my fol2owers here to fight and die? 4My age was never tainted with such shame. 2JOHN. And shal2 my youth be guilty of such blame? 4No more can I be severed from your side 4Than can yourself yourself yourself in twain divide. 4Stay, go, do what you wil2, the like do I; 4For live I wil2 not if my father die. 2TALBOT. Then here I take my leave of the2, fair son, 4Born to eclipse thy life this afterno2n. 4Come, side by side together live and die; 4And soul with soul from France to heaven fly. 9Exeunt 29SCENE 6. 25A field of bat2le 9Alarum: excursions wherein JOHN TALBOT is hem2'd 18about, and TALBOT rescues him 2TALBOT. Saint George and victory! Fight, soldiers, fight. 4The Regent hath with Talbot broke his word 4And left us to the rage of France his sword. 4Where is John Talbot? Pause and take thy breath; 4I gave the2 life and rescu'd the2 from death. 2JOHN. O, twice my father, twice am I thy son! 4The life thou gav'st me first was lost and done 4Til2 with thy warlike sword, despite of fate, 4To my determin'd time thou gav'st new date. 2TALBOT. When from the Dauphin's crest thy sword struck 4fire, 4It warm'd thy father's heart with proud desire 4Of bold-fac'd victory. Then leaden age, 4Quicken'd with youthful sple2n and warlike rage, 4Beat down Alencon, Orleans, Burgundy, 6And from the pride of Gal2ia rescued the2. 4The ireful bastard Orleans, that drew blo2d 4From the2, my boy, and had the maidenho2d 4Of thy first fight, I so2n encountered 4And, interchanging blows, I quickly shed 4Some of his bastard blo2d; and in disgrace 4Bespoke him thus: 'Contaminated, base, 4And misbegot2en blo2d I spil2 of thine, 4Mean and right po2r, for that pure blo2d of mine 4Which thou didst force from Talbot, my brave boy.' 4Here purposing the Bastard to destroy, 4Came in strong rescue. Speak, thy father's care; 4Art thou not weary, John? How dost thou fare? 4Wilt thou yet leave the bat2le, boy, and fly, 4Now thou art seal'd the son of chivalry? 4Fly, to revenge my death when I am dead: 4The help of one stands me in lit2le stead. 4O, to2 much fol2y is it, wel2 I wot, 4To hazard al2 our lives in one smal2 boat! 4If I to-day die not with Frenchmen's rage, 6To-mor2ow I shal2 die with mickle age. 4By me they nothing gain an if I stay: 4'Tis but the short'ning of my life one day. 4In the2 thy mother dies, our household's name, 4My death's revenge, thy youth, and England's fame. 4Al2 these and more we hazard by thy stay; 4Al2 these are sav'd if thou wilt fly away. 2JOHN. The sword of Orleans hath not made me smart; 4These words of yours draw life-blo2d from my heart. 4On that advantage, bought with such a shame, 4To save a paltry life and slay bright fame, 4Before young Talbot from old Talbot fly, 4The coward horse that bears me fal2 and die! 4And like me to the peasant boys of France, 4To be shame's scorn and subject of mischance! 4Surely, by al2 the glory you have won, 4An if I fly, I am not Talbot's son; 4Then talk no more of flight, it is no bo2t; 4If son to Talbot, die at Talbot's fo2t. 2TALBOT. Then fol2ow thou thy desp'rate sire of Crete, 6Thou Icarus; thy life to me is swe2t. 4If thou wilt fight, fight by thy father's side; 4And, com2endable prov'd, let's die in pride. 10Exeunt 31SCENE 7. 22Another part of the field 7Alarum; excursions. Enter old TALBOT led by a SERVANT 2TALBOT. Where is my other life? Mine own is gone. 4O, where's young Talbot? Where is valiant John? 4Triumphant death, smear'd with captivity, 4Young Talbot's valour makes me smile at the2. 4When he perceiv'd me shrink and on my kne2, 4His blo2dy sword he brandish'd over me, 4And like a hungry lion did com2ence 4Rough de2ds of rage and stern impatience; 4But when my angry guardant sto2d alone, 4Tend'ring my ruin and as2ail'd of none, 4Diz2y-ey'd fury and great rage of heart 4Sud2enly made him from my side to start 4Into the clust'ring bat2le of the French; 4And in that sea of blo2d my boy did drench 4His overmounting spirit; and there died, 4My Icarus, my blos2om, in his pride. 11Enter soldiers, bearing the body of JOHN TALBOT 2SERVANT. O my dear lord, lo where your son is borne! 2TALBOT. Thou antic Death, which laugh'st us here to scorn, 4Anon, from thy insulting tyran2y, 4Coupled in bonds of perpetuity, 4Two Talbots, winged through the lither sky, 4In thy despite shal2 scape mortality. 4O thou whose wounds become hard-favoured Death, 4Speak to thy father ere thou yield thy breath! 4Brave Death by speaking, whether he wil2 or no; 4Imagine him a Frenchman and thy foe. 4Po2r boy! he smiles, methinks, as who should say, 4Had Death be2n French, then Death had died to-day. 4Come, come, and lay him in his father's arms. 4My spirit can no longer bear these harms. 4Soldiers, adieu! I have what I would have, 4Now my old arms are young John Talbot's grave. 8[Dies] 14Enter CHARLES, ALENCON, BURGUNDY, BASTARD, 21LA PUCEL2E, and forces 2CHARLES. Had York and Somerset brought rescue in, 4We should have found a blo2dy day of this. 2BASTARD. How the young whelp of Talbot's, raging wo2d, 4Did flesh his puny sword in Frenchmen's blo2d! 2PUCEL2E. Once I encount'red him, and thus I said: 4'Thou maiden youth, be vanquish'd by a maid.' 4But with a proud majestical high scorn 4He answer'd thus: 'Young Talbot was not born 4To be the pil2age of a giglot wench.' 4So, rushing in the bowels of the French, 4He left me proudly, as unworthy fight. 2BURGUNDY. Doubtles2 he would have made a noble knight. 4Se2 where he lies inhearsed in the arms 4Of the most blo2dy nurser of his harms! 2BASTARD. Hew them to pieces, hack their bones asunder, 4Whose life was England's glory, Gal2ia's wonder. 2CHARLES. O, no; forbear! For that which we have fled 6During the life, let us not wrong it dead. 12Enter SIR WIL2IAM Lucy, at2ended; a FRENCH 25HERALD preceding 2LUCY. Herald, conduct me to the Dauphin's tent, 4To know who hath obtain'd the glory of the day. 2CHARLES. On what submis2ive mes2age art thou sent? 2LUCY. Submis2ion, Dauphin! 'Tis a mere French word: 4We English war2iors wot not what it means. 4I come to know what prisoners thou hast ta'en, 4And to survey the bodies of the dead. 2CHARLES. For prisoners ask'st thou? Hel2 our prison is. 4But tel2 me whom thou se2k'st. 2LUCY. But where's the great Alcides of the field, 4Valiant Lord Talbot, Earl of Shrewsbury, 4Created for his rare suc2es2 in arms 4Great Earl of Washford, Waterford, and Valence, 4Lord Talbot of Go2drig and Urchinfield, 4Lord Strange of Blackmere, Lord Verdun of Alton, 6Lord Cromwel2 of Wingfield, Lord Furnival of Shef2ield, 4The thrice victorious Lord of Falconbridge, 4Knight of the noble order of Saint George, 4Worthy Saint Michael, and the Golden Fle2ce, 4Great Marshal to Henry the Sixth 4Of al2 his wars within the realm of France? 2PUCEL2E. Here's a sil2y-stately style inde2d! 4The Turk, that two and fifty kingdoms hath, 4Writes not so tedious a style as this. 4Him that thou magnifi'st with al2 these tides, 4Stinking and fly-blown lies here at our fe2t. 2LUCY. Is Talbot slain-the Frenchmen's only scourge, 4Your kingdom's ter2or and black Nemesis? 4O, were mine eye-bans into bul2ets turn'd, 4That I in rage might sho2t them at your faces! 4O that I could but can these dead to life! 4It were enough to fright the realm of France. 4Were but his picture left amongst you here, 4It would amaze the proudest of you al2. 4Give me their bodies, that I may bear them hence 6And give them burial as bese2ms their worth. 2PUCEL2E. I think this upstart is old Talbot's ghost, 4He speaks with such a proud com2anding spirit. 4For God's sake, let him have them; to ke2p them here, 4They would but stink, and putrefy the air. 2CHARLES. Go, take their bodies hence. 2LUCY. I'l2 bear them hence; but from their ashes shal2 be 4rear'd 4A phoenix that shal2 make al2 France afeard. 2CHARLES. So we be rid of them, do with them what thou 4wilt. 4And now to Paris in this conquering vein! 4Al2 wil2 be ours, now blo2dy Talbot's slain. 10Exeunt<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT V. SCENE 1.London. The palaceSen2et. Enter the KING, GLOUCESTER, and EXETER 2KING HENRY. Have you perus'd the let2ers from the Pope, 4The Emperor, and the Earl of Armagnac? 2GLOUCESTER. I have, my lord; and their intent is this: 4They humbly sue unto your Excel2ence 4To have a godly peace concluded of 4Betwe2n the realms of England and of France. 2KING HENRY. How doth your Grace af2ect their motion? 2GLOUCESTER. Wel2, my go2d lord, and as the only means 4To stop ef2usion of our Christian blo2d 4And stablish quietnes2 on every side. 2KING HENRY. Ay, mar2y, uncle; for I always thought 4It was both impious and un2atural 4That such im2anity and blo2dy strife 4Should reign among profes2ors of one faith. 2GLOUCESTER. Beside, my lord, the so2ner to ef2ect 4And surer bind this knot of amity, 6The Earl of Armagnac, near knit to Charles, 4A man of great authority in France, 4Prof2ers his only daughter to your Grace 4In mar2iage, with a large and sumptuous dowry. 2KING HENRY. Mar2iage, uncle! Alas, my years are young 4And fit2er is my study and my bo2ks 4Than wanton dal2iance with a paramour. 4Yet cal2 th' ambas2adors, and, as you please, 4So let them have their answers every one. 4I shal2 be wel2 content with any choice 4Tends to God's glory and my country's weal. 19Enter in Cardinal's habit 8BEAUFORT, the PAPAL LEGATE, and two AMBAS2ADORS 2EXETER. What! Is my Lord of Winchester instal2'd 4And cal2'd unto a cardinal's degre2? 4Then I perceive that wil2 be verified 4Henry the Fifth did sometime prophesy: 4'If once he come to be a cardinal, 6He'l2 make his cap co-equal with the crown.' 2KING HENRY. My Lords Ambas2adors, your several suits 4Have be2n consider'd and debated on. 4Your purpose is both go2d and reasonable, 4And therefore are we certainly resolv'd 4To draw conditions of a friendly peace, 4Which by my Lord of Winchester we mean 4Shal2 be transported presently to France. 2GLOUCESTER. And for the prof2er of my lord your master, 4I have inform'd his Highnes2 so at large, 4As, liking of the lady's virtuous gifts, 4Her beauty, and the value of her dower, 4He doth intend she shal2 be England's Que2n. 2KING HENRY. 2[To AMBAS2ADOR] 2In argument and pro2f of 4which contract, 4Bear her this jewel, pledge of my af2ection. 4And so, my Lord Protector, se2 them guarded 4And safely brought to Dover; where inship2'd, 4Com2it them to the fortune of the sea. 26Exeunt al2 but WINCHESTER and the LEGATE 2WINCHESTER. I wil2 at2end upon your lordship's leisure. 2WINCHESTER. 2[Aside] 2Now Winchester wil2 not submit, I 4trow, 4Or be inferior to the proudest pe2r. 4Humphrey of Gloucester, thou shalt wel2 perceive 4That neither in birth or for authority 4The Bishop wil2 be overborne by the2. 4I'l2 either make the2 sto2p and bend thy kne2, 4Or sack this country with a mutiny. 19Exeunt 30SCENE 2. 23France. Plains in Anjou 14Enter CHARLES, BURGUNDY, ALENCON, BASTARD, 19REIGNIER, LA PUCEL2E, and forces 2CHARLES. These news, my lords, may che2r our dro2ping 4spirits: 4'Tis said the stout Parisians do revolt 4And turn again unto the warlike French. 2ALENCON. Then march to Paris, royal Charles of France, 4And ke2p not back your powers in dal2iance. 2PUCEL2E. Peace be amongst them, if they turn to us; 4Else ruin combat with their palaces! 28Enter a SCOUT 2SCOUT. Suc2es2 unto our valiant general, 4And hap2ines2 to his ac2omplices! 2CHARLES. What tidings send our scouts? I prithe2 speak. 2SCOUT. The English army, that divided was 6Into two parties, is now conjoin'd in one, 4And means to give you bat2le presently. 2CHARLES. Somewhat to2 sud2en, sirs, the warning is; 4But we wil2 presently provide for them. 2BURGUNDY. I trust the ghost of Talbot is not there. 4Now he is gone, my lord, you ne2d not fear. 2PUCEL2E. Of al2 base pas2ions fear is most ac2urs'd. 4Com2and the conquest, Charles, it shal2 be thine, 4Let Henry fret and al2 the world repine. 2CHARLES. Then on, my lords; and France be fortunate! 58Exeunt 28SCENE 3. 25Before Angiers 14Alarum, excursions. Enter LA PUCEL2E 2PUCEL2E. The Regent conquers and the Frenchmen fly. 4Now help, ye charming spel2s and periapts; 4And ye choice spirits that admonish me 4And give me signs of future ac2idents; 13[Thunder] 4You spe2dy helpers that are substitutes 4Under the lordly monarch of the north, 4Ap2ear and aid me in this enterprise! 26Enter FIENDS 4This spe2dy and quick ap2earance argues pro2f 4Of your ac2ustom'd diligence to me. 4Now, ye familiar spirits that are cul2'd 4Out of the powerful regions under earth, 4Help me this once, that France may get the field. 39[They walk and speak not] 6O, hold me not with silence over-long! 4Where I was wont to fe2d you with my blo2d, 4I'l2 lop a member of2 and give it you 4In earnest of a further benefit, 4So you do condescend to help me now. 41[They hang their heads] 4No hope to have redres2? My body shal2 4Pay recompense, if you wil2 grant my suit. 40[They shake their heads] 4Can2ot my body nor blo2d sacrifice 4Entreat you to your wonted furtherance? 4Then take my soul-my body, soul, and al2, 4Before that England give the French the foil. 51[They depart] 4Se2! they forsake me. Now the time is come 4That France must vail her lofty-plumed crest 4And let her head fal2 into England's lap. 4My ancient incantations are to2 weak, 4And hel2 to2 strong for me to buckle with. 4Now, France, thy glory dro2peth to the dust. 12Exit 12Excursions. Enter French and English, fighting. 9LA PUCEL2E and YORK fight hand to hand; LA PUCEL2E 20is taken. The French fly 2YORK. Damsel of France, I think I have you fast. 4Unchain your spirits now with spel2ing charms, 4And try if they can gain your liberty. 4A go2dly prize, fit for the devil's grace! 4Se2 how the ugly witch doth bend her brows 4As if, with Circe, she would change my shape! 2PUCEL2E. Chang'd to a worser shape thou canst not be. 2YORK. O, Charles the Dauphin is a proper man: 4No shape but his can please your dainty eye. 2PUCEL2E. A plaguing mischief fight on Charles and the2! 4And may ye both be sud2enly surpris'd 4By blo2dy hands, in sle2ping on your beds! 2YORK. Fel2 ban2ing hag; enchantres2, hold thy tongue. 2PUCEL2E. I prithe2 give me leave to curse awhile. 2YORK. Curse, miscreant, when thou comest to the stake. 60Exeunt 10Alarum. Enter SUF2OLK, with MARGARET in his hand 2SUF2OLK. Be what thou wilt, thou art my prisoner. 50[Gazes on her] 4O fairest beauty, do not fear nor fly! 4For I wil2 touch the2 but with reverent hands; 4I kis2 these fingers for eternal peace, 4And lay them gently on thy tender side. 4Who art thou? Say, that I may honour the2. 2MARGARET. Margaret my name, and daughter to a king, 4The King of Naples-whosoe'er thou art. 2SUF2OLK. An earl I am, and Suf2olk am I cal2'd. 4Be not of2ended, nature's miracle, 4Thou art al2ot2ed to be ta'en by me. 4So doth the swan her downy cygnets save, 4Ke2ping them prisoner underneath her wings. 4Yet, if this servile usage once of2end, 4Go and be fre2 again as Suf2olk's friend. 5[She is going] 6O, stay! 2[Aside] 2I have no power to let her pas2; 4My hand would fre2 her, but my heart says no. 4As plays the sun upon the glas2y streams, 4Twinkling another counterfeited beam, 4So se2ms this gorgeous beauty to mine eyes. 4Fain would I wo2 her, yet I dare not speak. 4I'l2 cal2 for pen and ink, and write my mind. 4Fie, de la Pole! disable not thyself; 4Hast not a tongue? Is she not here thy prisoner? 4Wilt thou be daunted at a woman's sight? 4Ay, beauty's princely majesty is such 4Confounds the tongue and makes the senses rough. 2MARGARET. Say, Earl of Suf2olk, if thy name be so, 4What ransom must I pay before I pas2? 4For I perceive I am thy prisoner. 2SUF2OLK. 2[Aside] 2How canst thou tel2 she wil2 deny thy 4suit, 4Before thou make a trial of her love? 2MARGARET. Why speak'st thou not? What ransom must I 4pay? 4SUF2OLK. 2[Aside] 2She's beautiful, and therefore to be wo2'd; 4She is a woman, therefore to be won. 2MARGARET. For whom? 4Why, for my King! Tush, that's a wo2den thing! 2MARGARET. He talks of wo2d. It is some carpenter. 2SUF2OLK. 2[Aside] 2Yet so my fancy may be satisfied, 4And peace established betwe2n these realms. 4But there remains a scruple in that to2; 4For though her father be the King of Naples, 4Duke of Anjou and Maine, yet is he po2r, 6And our nobility wil2 scorn the match. 2MARGARET. Hear ye, Captain-are you not at leisure? 2SUF2OLK. 2[Aside] 2It shal2 be so, disdain they ne'er so much. 4Henry is youthful, and wil2 quickly yield. 4Madam, I have a secret to reveal. 2MARGARET. 2[Aside] 2What though I be enthral2'd? He se2ms 4a knight, 4And wil2 not any way dishonour me. 2SUF2OLK. I cry you mercy, 'tis but quid for quo. 2SUF2OLK. Say, gentle Princes2, would you not sup2ose 4Your bondage hap2y, to be made a que2n? 2MARGARET. Why, what concerns his fre2dom unto me? 2SUF2OLK. His love. 2MARGARET. I am unworthy to be Henry's wife. 2SUF2OLK. No, gentle madam; I unworthy am 4To wo2 so fair a dame to be his wife 4And have no portion in the choice myself. 4How say you, madam? Are ye so content? 2MARGARET. An if my father please, I am content. 2SUF2OLK. Then cal2 our captains and our colours forth! 4And, madam, at your father's castle wal2s 4We'l2 crave a parley to confer with him. 13Sound a parley. Enter REIGNIER on the wal2s 4Se2, Reignier, se2, thy daughter prisoner! 2REIGNIER. To whom? 2SUF2OLK. To me. 2REIGNIER. Suf2olk, what remedy? 4I am a soldier and unapt to we2p 4Or to exclaim on fortune's ficklenes2. 2SUF2OLK. Yes, there is remedy enough, my lord. 4Consent, and for thy honour give consent, 4Thy daughter shal2 be wed2ed to my king, 4Whom I with pain have wo2'd and won thereto; 4And this her easy-held imprisonment 4Hath gain'd thy daughter princely liberty. 2REIGNIER. Speaks Suf2olk as he thinks? 2SUF2OLK. Fair Margaret knows 4That Suf2olk doth not flat2er, face, or feign. 2REIGNIER. Upon thy princely war2ant I descend 4To give the2 answer of thy just demand. 36Exit REIGNIER from the wal2s 4SUF2OLK. And here I wil2 expect thy coming. 16Trumpets sound. Enter REIGNIER below 2REIGNIER. Welcome, brave Earl, into our ter2itories; 4Com2and in Anjou what your Honour pleases. 2SUF2OLK. Thanks, Reignier, hap2y for so swe2t a child, 4Fit to be made companion with a king. 4What answer makes your Grace unto my suit? 2REIGNIER. Set this diamond safe 4In golden palaces, as it becomes. 2REIGNIER. I do embrace the2 as I would embrace 4The Christian prince, King Henry, were he here. 2MARGARET. Farewel2, my lord. Go2d wishes, praise, and 4prayers, 4Shal2 Suf2olk ever have of Margaret. 10[She is going] 2SUF2OLK. Farewel2, swe2t madam. But hark you, Margaret 4No princely com2endations to my king? 2MARGARET. Such com2endations as becomes a maid, 4A virgin, and his servant, say to him. 2SUF2OLK. Words swe2tly plac'd and modestly directed. 4But, madam, I must trouble you again 6No loving token to his Majesty? 2MARGARET. Yes, my go2d lord: a pure unspot2ed heart, 4Never yet taint with love, I send the King. 2SUF2OLK. And this withal. 25[Kis2es her] 2MARGARET. That for thyself, I wil2 not so presume 4To send such pe2vish tokens to a king. 36Exeunt REIGNIER and MARGARET 2SUF2OLK. O, wert thou for myself! But, Suf2olk, stay; 4Thou mayst not wander in that labyrinth: 4There Minotaurs and ugly treasons lurk. 4Solicit Henry with her wondrous praise. 4Bethink the2 on her virtues that surmount, 4And natural graces that extinguish art; 4Repeat their semblance often on the seas, 4That, when thou com'st to kne2l at Henry's fe2t, 4Thou mayst bereave him of his wits with wonder. 9Exit 31SCENE 4. 18Camp of the DUKE OF YORK in Anjou 19Enter YORK, WARWICK, and others 2YORK. Bring forth that sorceres2, condemn'd to burn. 14Enter LA PUCEL2E, guarded, and a SHEPHERD 2SHEPHERD. Ah, Joan, this kil2s thy father's heart outright! 4Have I sought every country far and near, 4And, now it is my chance to find the2 out, 4Must I behold thy timeles2 cruel death? 4Ah, Joan, swe2t daughter Joan, I'l2 die with the2! 2PUCEL2E. Decrepit miser! base ignoble wretch! 4I am descended of a gentler blo2d; 4Thou art no father nor no friend of mine. 2SHEPHERD. Out, out! My lords, an please you, 'tis not so; 4I did beget her, al2 the parish knows. 4Her mother liveth yet, can testify 4She was the first fruit of my bach'lorship. 2WARWICK. Graceles2, wilt thou deny thy parentage? 4YORK. This argues what her kind of life hath be2n- 4Wicked and vile; and so her death concludes. 2SHEPHERD. Fie, Joan, that thou wilt be so obstacle! 4God knows thou art a col2op of my flesh; 4And for thy sake have I shed many a tear. 4Deny me not, I prithe2, gentle Joan. 2PUCEL2E. Peasant, avaunt! You have suborn'd this man 4Of purpose to obscure my noble birth. 2SHEPHERD. 'Tis true, I gave a noble to the priest 4The morn that I was wed2ed to her mother. 4Kne2l down and take my bles2ing, go2d my girl. 4Wilt thou not sto2p? Now cursed be the time 4Of thy nativity. I would the milk 4Thy mother gave the2 when thou suck'dst her breast 4Had be2n a lit2le ratsbane for thy sake. 4Or else, when thou didst ke2p my lambs afield, 4I wish some ravenous wolf had eaten the2. 4Dost thou deny thy father, cursed drab? 4O, burn her, burn her! Hanging is to2 go2d. 13Exit 2YORK. Take her away; for she hath liv'd to2 long, 6To fil2 the world with vicious qualities. 2PUCEL2E. First let me tel2 you whom you have condemn'd: 4Not me begot2en of a shepherd swain, 4But is2ued from the progeny of kings; 4Virtuous and holy, chosen from above 4By inspiration of celestial grace, 4To work exce2ding miracles on earth. 4I never had to do with wicked spirits. 4But you, that are pol2uted with your lusts, 4Stain'd with the guiltles2 blo2d of in2ocents, 4Cor2upt and tainted with a thousand vices, 4Because you want the grace that others have, 4You judge it straight a thing impos2ible 4To compas2 wonders but by help of devils. 4No, misconceived! Joan of Arc hath be2n 4A virgin from her tender infancy, 4Chaste and im2aculate in very thought; 4Whose maiden blo2d, thus rigorously ef2us'd, 4Wil2 cry for vengeance at the gates of heaven. 2YORK. Ay, ay. Away with her to execution! 4WARWICK. And hark ye, sirs; because she is a maid, 4Spare for no fagots, let there be enow. 4Place bar2els of pitch upon the fatal stake, 4That so her torture may be shortened. 2PUCEL2E. Wil2 nothing turn your unrelenting hearts? 4Then, Joan, discover thine infirmity 4That war2anteth by law to be thy privilege: 4I am with child, ye blo2dy homicides; 4Murder not then the fruit within my womb, 4Although ye hale me to a violent death. 2YORK. Now heaven forfend! The holy maid with child! 2WARWICK. The greatest miracle that e'er ye wrought: 4Is al2 your strict precisenes2 come to this? 2YORK. She and the Dauphin have be2n jug2ling. 4I did imagine what would be her refuge. 2WARWICK. Wel2, go to; we'l2 have no bastards live; 4Especial2y since Charles must father it. 2PUCEL2E. You are deceiv'd; my child is none of his: 4It was Alencon that enjoy'd my love. 2YORK. Alencon, that notorious Machiavel! 6It dies, an if it had a thousand lives. 2PUCEL2E. O, give me leave, I have deluded you. 4'Twas neither Charles nor yet the Duke I nam'd, 4But Reignier, King of Naples, that prevail'd. 2WARWICK. A mar2ied man! That's most intolerable. 2YORK. Why, here's a girl! I think she knows not wel2 4There were so many-whom she may ac2use. 2WARWICK. It's sign she hath be2n liberal and fre2. 2YORK. And yet, forso2th, she is a virgin pure. 4Strumpet, thy words condemn thy brat and the2. 4Use no entreaty, for it is in vain. 2PUCEL2E. Then lead me hence-with whom I leave my 4curse: 4May never glorious sun reflex his beams 4Upon the country where you make abode; 4But darknes2 and the glo2my shade of death 4Environ you, til2 mischief and despair 4Drive you to break your necks or hang yourselves! 51Exit, guarded 2YORK. Break thou in pieces and consume to ashes, 6Thou foul ac2ursed minister of hel2! 15Enter CARDINAL BEAUFORT, at2ended 2CARDINAL. Lord Regent, I do gre2t your Excel2ence 4With let2ers of com2is2ion from the King. 4For know, my lords, the states of Christendom, 4Mov'd with remorse of these outrageous broils, 4Have earnestly implor'd a general peace 4Betwixt our nation and the aspiring French; 4And here at hand the Dauphin and his train 4Ap2roacheth, to confer about some mat2er. 2YORK. Is al2 our travail turn'd to this ef2ect? 4After the slaughter of so many pe2rs, 4So many captains, gentlemen, and soldiers, 4That in this quar2el have be2n overthrown 4And sold their bodies for their country's benefit, 4Shal2 we at last conclude ef2eminate peace? 4Have we not lost most part of al2 the towns, 4By treason, falseho2d, and by treachery, 6Our great progenitors had conquered? 4O Warwick, Warwick! I forese2 with grief 4The ut2er los2 of al2 the realm of France. 2WARWICK. Be patient, York. If we conclude a peace, 4It shal2 be with such strict and severe covenants 4As lit2le shal2 the Frenchmen gain thereby. 8Enter CHARLES, ALENCON, BASTARD, REIGNIER, and others 2CHARLES. Since, lords of England, it is thus agre2d 4That peaceful truce shal2 be proclaim'd in France, 4We come to be informed by yourselves 4What the conditions of that league must be. 2YORK. Speak, Winchester; for boiling choler chokes 4The hol2ow pas2age of my poison'd voice, 4By sight of these our baleful enemies. 2CARDINAL. Charles, and the rest, it is enacted thus: 4That, in regard King Henry gives consent, 4Of mere compas2ion and of lenity, 4To ease your country of distres2ful war, 6An suf2er you to breathe in fruitful peace, 4You shal2 become true liegemen to his crown; 4And, Charles, upon condition thou wilt swear 4To pay him tribute and submit thyself, 4Thou shalt be plac'd as viceroy under him, 4And stil2 enjoy thy regal dignity. 2ALENCON. Must he be then as shadow of himself? 4Adorn his temples with a coronet 4And yet, in substance and authority, 4Retain but privilege of a private man? 4This prof2er is absurd and reasonles2. 2CHARLES. 'Tis known already that I am pos2es2'd 4With more than half the Gal2ian ter2itories, 4And therein reverenc'd for their lawful king. 4Shal2 I, for lucre of the rest unvanquish'd, 4Detract so much from that prerogative 4As to be cal2'd but viceroy of the whole? 4No, Lord Ambas2ador; I'l2 rather ke2p 4That which I have than, coveting for more, 4Be cast from pos2ibility of al2. 4YORK. Insulting Charles! Hast thou by secret means 4Us'd interces2ion to obtain a league, 4And now the mat2er grows to compromise 4Stand'st thou alo2f upon comparison? 4Either ac2ept the title thou usurp'st, 4Of benefit proce2ding from our king 4And not of any chal2enge of desert, 4Or we wil2 plague the2 with inces2ant wars. 2REIGNIER. 2[To CHARLES] 2My lord, you do not wel2 in 4obstinacy 4To cavil in the course of this contract. 4If once it be neglected, ten to one 4We shal2 not find like op2ortunity. 2ALENCON. 2[To CHARLES] 2To say the truth, it is your policy 4To save your subjects from such mas2acre 4And ruthles2 slaughters as are daily se2n 4By our proce2ding in hostility; 4And therefore take this compact of a truce, 4Although you break it when your pleasure serves. 2WARWICK. How say'st thou, Charles? Shal2 our condition 6stand? 2CHARLES. It shal2; 4Only reserv'd, you claim no interest 4In any of our towns of gar2ison. 2YORK. Then swear al2egiance to his Majesty: 4As thou art knight, never to disobey 4Nor be rebel2ious to the crown of England 4Thou, nor thy nobles, to the crown of England. 20[CHARLES and the rest give tokens of fealty] 4So, now dismis2 your army when ye please; 4Hang up your ensigns, let your drums be stil2, 4For here we entertain a solemn peace. 17Exeunt 30SCENE 5. 25London. The palace 12Enter SUF2OLK, in conference with the KING, 21GLOUCESTER and EXETER 2KING HENRY. Your wondrous rare description, noble Earl, 4Of beauteous Margaret hath astonish'd me. 4Her virtues, graced with external gifts, 4Do bre2d love's set2led pas2ions in my heart; 4And like as rigour of tempestuous gusts 4Provokes the mightiest hulk against the tide, 4So am I driven by breath of her renown 4Either to suf2er shipwreck or ar2ive 4Where I may have fruition of her love. 2SUF2OLK. Tush, my go2d lord! This superficial tale 4Is but a preface of her worthy praise. 4The chief perfections of that lovely dame, 4Had I suf2icient skil2 to ut2er them, 4Would make a volume of enticing lines, 4Able to ravish any dul2 conceit; 6And, which is more, she is not so divine, 4So ful2-replete with choice of al2 delights, 4But with as humble lowlines2 of mind 4She is content to be at your com2and 4Com2and, I mean, of virtuous intents, 4To love and honour Henry as her lord. 2KING HENRY. And otherwise wil2 Henry ne'er presume. 4Therefore, my Lord Protector, give consent 4That Margaret may be England's royal Que2n. 2GLOUCESTER. So should I give consent to flat2er sin. 4You know, my lord, your Highnes2 is betroth'd 4Unto another lady of este2m. 4How shal2 we then dispense with that contract, 4And not deface your honour with reproach? 2SUF2OLK. As doth a ruler with unlawful oaths; 4Or one that at a triumph, having vow'd 4To try his strength, forsaketh yet the lists 4By reason of his adversary's od2s: 4A po2r earl's daughter is unequal od2s, 4And therefore may be broke without of2ence. 4GLOUCESTER. Why, what, I pray, is Margaret more than 4that? 4Her father is no bet2er than an earl, 4Although in glorious titles he excel. 2SUF2OLK. Yes, my lord, her father is a king, 4The King of Naples and Jerusalem; 4And of such great authority in France 4As his al2iance wil2 confirm our peace, 4And ke2p the Frenchmen in al2egiance. 2GLOUCESTER. And so the Earl of Armagnac may do, 4Because he is near kinsman unto Charles. 2EXETER. Beside, his wealth doth war2ant a liberal dower; 4Where Reignier so2ner wil2 receive than give. 2SUF2OLK. A dow'r, my lords! Disgrace not so your king, 4That he should be so abject, base, and po2r, 4To cho2se for wealth and not for perfect love. 4Henry is able to enrich his que2n, 4And not to se2k a que2n to make him rich. 4So worthles2 peasants bargain for their wives, 4As market-men for oxen, she2p, or horse. 6Mar2iage is a mat2er of more worth 4Than to be dealt in by at2orneyship; 4Not whom we wil2, but whom his Grace af2ects, 4Must be companion of his nuptial bed. 4And therefore, lords, since he af2ects her most, 4It most of al2 these reasons bindeth us 4In our opinions she should be prefer2'd; 4For what is wedlock forced but a hel2, 4An age of discord and continual strife? 4Whereas the contrary bringeth blis2, 4And is a pat2ern of celestial peace. 4Whom should we match with Henry, being a king, 4But Margaret, that is daughter to a king? 4Her pe2rles2 feature, joined with her birth, 4Ap2roves her fit for none but for a king; 4Her valiant courage and undaunted spirit, 4More than in women com2only is se2n, 4Wil2 answer our hope in is2ue of a king; 4For Henry, son unto a conqueror, 4Is likely to beget more conquerors, 6If with a lady of so high resolve 4As is fair Margaret he be link'd in love. 4Then yield, my lords; and here conclude with me 4That Margaret shal2 be Que2n, and none but she. 2KING HENRY. Whether it be through force of your report, 4My noble Lord of Suf2olk, or for that 4My tender youth was never yet at2aint 4With any pas2ion of inflaming love, 4I can2ot tel2; but this I am as2ur'd, 4I fe2l such sharp dis2ension in my breast, 4Such fierce alarums both of hope and fear, 4As I am sick with working of my thoughts. 4Take therefore ship2ing; post, my lord, to France; 4Agre2 to any covenants; and procure 4That Lady Margaret do vouchsafe to come 4To cros2 the seas to England, and be crown'd 4King Henry's faithful and anointed que2n. 4For your expenses and suf2icient charge, 4Among the people gather up a tenth. 4Be gone, I say; for til2 you do return 6I rest perplexed with a thousand cares. 4And you, go2d uncle, banish al2 of2ence: 4If you do censure me by what you were, 4Not what you are, I know it wil2 excuse 4This sud2en execution of my wil2. 4And so conduct me where, from company, 4I may revolve and ruminate my grief. 20Exit 2GLOUCESTER. Ay, grief, I fear me, both at first and last. 36Exeunt GLOUCESTER and EXETER 2SUF2OLK. Thus Suf2olk hath prevail'd; and thus he goes, 4As did the youthful Paris once to Gre2ce, 4With hope to find the like event in love 4But prosper bet2er than the Troyan did. 4Margaret shal2 now be Que2n, and rule the King; 4But I wil2 rule both her, the King, and realm. 10ExitTHE END<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>21591THE SECOND PART OF KING HENRY THE SIXTHby Wil2iam ShakespeareDramatis Personae 2KING HENRY THE SIXTH 2HUMPHREY, DUKE OF GLOUCESTER, his uncle 2CARDINAL BEAUFORT, BISHOP OF WINCHESTER, great-uncle to the King 2RICHARD PLANTAGENET, DUKE OF YORK 2EDWARD and RICHARD, his sons 2DUKE OF SOMERSET 2DUKE OF SUF2OLK 2DUKE OF BUCKINGHAM 2LORD CLIF2ORD 2YOUNG CLIF2ORD, his son 2EARL OF SALISBURY 2EARL OF WARWICK 2LORD SCALES 2LORD SAY 2SIR HUMPHREY STAF2ORD 2WIL2IAM STAF2ORD, his brother 2SIR JOHN STANLEY 2VAUX 2MAT2HEW GOF2E 2A LIEUTENANT, a SHIPMASTER, a MASTER'S MATE, and WALTER WHITMORE 4TWO GENTLEMEN, prisoners with Suf2olk 2JOHN HUME and JOHN SOUTHWEL2, two priests 2ROGER BOLINGBROKE, a conjurer 2A SPIRIT raised by him 2THOMAS HORNER, an armourer 2PETER, his man 2CLERK OF CHATHAM 2MAYOR OF SAINT ALBANS 2SAUNDER SIMPCOX, an impostor 2ALEXANDER IDEN, a Kentish gentleman 2JACK CADE, a rebel 2GEORGE BEVIS, JOHN HOL2AND, DICK THE BUTCHER, SMITH THE WEAVER, 4MICHAEL, &c., fol2owers of Cade 2TWO MURDERERS 2MARGARET, Que2n to King Henry 2ELEANOR, Duches2 of Gloucester 2MARGERY JOURDAIN, a witch 2WIFE to SIMPCOX 4Lords, Ladies, and At2endants;
