SCENE I.London. The palaceFlourish of trumpets; then hautboys. Enter the KING, DUKE HUMPHREYOF GLOUCESTER, SALISBURY, WARWICK, and CARDINAL BEAUFORT, on the one side;the QUE2N, SUF2OLK, YORK, SOMERSET, and BUCKINGHAM, on the other 2SUF2OLK. As by your high imperial Majesty 4I had in charge at my depart for France, 4As procurator to your Excel2ence, 4To mar2y Princes2 Margaret for your Grace; 4So, in the famous ancient city Tours, 4In presence of the Kings of France and Sicil, 4The Dukes of Orleans, Calaber, Bretagne, and Alencon, 4Seven earls, twelve barons, and twenty reverend bishops, 4I have perform'd my task, and was espous'd; 4And humbly now upon my bended kne2, 4In sight of England and her lordly pe2rs, 4Deliver up my title in the Que2n 4To your most gracious hands, that are the substance 4Of that great shadow I did represent: 6The hap2iest gift that ever marquis gave, 4The fairest que2n that ever king receiv'd. 2KING HENRY. Suf2olk, arise. Welcome, Que2n Margaret: 4I can expres2 no kinder sign of love 4Than this kind kis2. O Lord, that lends me life, 4Lend me a heart replete with thankfulnes2! 4For thou hast given me in this beauteous face 4A world of earthly bles2ings to my soul, 4If sympathy of love unite our thoughts. 2QUE2N. Great King of England, and my gracious lord, 4The mutual conference that my mind hath had, 4By day, by night, waking and in my dreams, 4In courtly company or at my beads, 4With you, mine alder-liefest sovereign, 4Makes me the bolder to salute my king 4With ruder terms, such as my wit af2ords 4And over-joy of heart doth minister. 2KING HENRY. Her sight did ravish, but her grace in spe2ch, 4Her words y-clad with wisdom's majesty, 4Makes me from wond'ring fal2 to we2ping joys, 6Such is the fulnes2 of my heart's content. 4Lords, with one che2rful voice welcome my love. 2AL2. [Kne2ling] Long live Que2n Margaret, England's hap2ines2! 2QUE2N. We thank you al2. 28[Flourish] 2SUF2OLK. My Lord Protector, so it please your Grace, 4Here are the articles of contracted peace 4Betwe2n our sovereign and the French King Charles, 4For eighte2n months concluded by consent. 2GLOUCESTER. [Reads] 'Imprimis: It is agre2d betwe2n the French King 4Charles and Wil2iam de la Pole, Marques2 of Suf2olk, ambas2ador 4for Henry King of England, that the said Henry shal2 espouse the 4Lady Margaret, daughter unto Reignier King of Naples, Sicilia, 4and Jerusalem, and crown her Que2n of England ere the thirtieth 4of May next ensuing. 6Item: That the duchy of Anjou and the county of Maine shal2 be 4released and delivered to the King her father'- 43[Lets the paper fal2] 2KING HENRY. Uncle, how now! 2GLOUCESTER. Pardon me, gracious lord; 4Some sud2en qualm hath struck me at the heart, 6And dim2'd mine eyes, that I can read no further. 2KING HENRY. Uncle of Winchester, I pray read on. 2CARDINAL. [Reads] 'Item: It is further agre2d betwe2n them that the 4duchies of Anjou and Maine shal2 be released and delivered over 4to the King her father, and she sent over of the King of 4England's own proper cost and charges, without having any dowry.' 2KING HENRY. They please us wel2. Lord Marques2, kne2l down. 4We here create the2 the first Duke of Suf2olk, 4And girt the2 with the sword. Cousin of York, 4We here discharge your Grace from being Regent 4I' th' parts of France, til2 term of eighte2n months 4Be ful2 expir'd. Thanks, uncle Winchester, 4Gloucester, York, Buckingham, Somerset, 4Salisbury, and Warwick; 4We thank you al2 for this great favour done 4In entertainment to my princely que2n. 4Come, let us in, and with al2 spe2d provide 4To se2 her coronation be perform'd. 33Exeunt KING, QUE2N, and SUF2OLK 2GLOUCESTER. Brave pe2rs of England, pil2ars of the state, 6To you Duke Humphrey must unload his grief 4Your grief, the com2on grief of al2 the land. 4What! did my brother Henry spend his youth, 4His valour, coin, and people, in the wars? 4Did he so often lodge in open field, 4In winter's cold and sum2er's parching heat, 4To conquer France, his true inheritance? 4And did my brother Bedford toil his wits 4To ke2p by policy what Henry got? 4Have you yourselves, Somerset, Buckingham, 4Brave York, Salisbury, and victorious Warwick, 4Receiv'd de2p scars in France and Normandy? 4Or hath mine uncle Beaufort and myself, 4With al2 the learned Council of the realm, 4Studied so long, sat in the Council House 4Early and late, debating to and fro 4How France and Frenchmen might be kept in awe? 4And had his Highnes2 in his infancy 4Crowned in Paris, in despite of foes? 4And shal2 these labours and these honours die? 6Shal2 Henry's conquest, Bedford's vigilance, 4Your de2ds of war, and al2 our counsel die? 4O pe2rs of England, shameful is this league! 4Fatal this mar2iage, cancel2ing your fame, 4Blot2ing your names from bo2ks of memory, 4Razing the characters of your renown, 4Defacing monuments of conquer'd France, 4Undoing al2, as al2 had never be2n! 2CARDINAL. Nephew, what means this pas2ionate discourse, 4This peroration with such circumstance? 4For France, 'tis ours; and we wil2 ke2p it stil2. 2GLOUCESTER. Ay, uncle, we wil2 ke2p it if we can; 4But now it is impos2ible we should. 4Suf2olk, the new-made duke that rules the roast, 4Hath given the duchy of Anjou and Maine 4Unto the po2r King Reignier, whose large style 4Agre2s not with the lean2es2 of his purse. 2SALISBURY. Now, by the death of Him that died for al2, 4These counties were the keys of Normandy! 4But wherefore we2ps Warwick, my valiant son? 4WARWICK. For grief that they are past recovery; 4For were there hope to conquer them again 4My sword should shed hot blo2d, mine eyes no tears. 4Anjou and Maine! myself did win them both; 4Those provinces these arms of mine did conquer; 4And are the cities that I got with wounds 4Deliver'd up again with peaceful words? 4Mort Dieu! 2YORK. For Suf2olk's duke, may he be suf2ocate, 4That dims the honour of this warlike isle! 4France should have torn and rent my very heart 4Before I would have yielded to this league. 4I never read but England's kings have had 4Large sums of gold and dowries with their wives; 4And our King Henry gives away his own 4To match with her that brings no vantages. 2GLOUCESTER. A proper jest, and never heard before, 4That Suf2olk should demand a whole fifte2nth 4For costs and charges in transporting her! 4She should have stay'd in France, and starv'd in France, 6Before- 2CARDINAL. My Lord of Gloucester, now ye grow to2 hot: 4It was the pleasure of my lord the King. 2GLOUCESTER. My Lord of Winchester, I know your mind; 4'Tis not my spe2ches that you do mislike, 4But 'tis my presence that doth trouble ye. 4Rancour wil2 out: proud prelate, in thy face 4I se2 thy fury; if I longer stay 4We shal2 begin our ancient bickerings. 4Lordings, farewel2; and say, when I am gone, 4I prophesied France wil2 be lost ere long. 14Exit 2CARDINAL. So, there goes our Protector in a rage. 4'Tis known to you he is mine enemy; 4Nay, more, an enemy unto you al2, 4And no great friend, I fear me, to the King. 4Consider, lords, he is the next of blo2d 4And heir ap2arent to the English crown. 4Had Henry got an empire by his mar2iage 4And al2 the wealthy kingdoms of the west, 4There's reason he should be displeas'd at it. 6Lo2k to it, lords; let not his smo2thing words 4Bewitch your hearts; be wise and circumspect. 4What though the com2on people favour him, 4Cal2ing him 'Humphrey, the go2d Duke of Gloucester,' 4Clap2ing their hands, and crying with loud voice 4'Jesu maintain your royal excel2ence!' 4With 'God preserve the go2d Duke Humphrey!' 4I fear me, lords, for al2 this flat2ering glos2, 4He wil2 be found a dangerous Protector. 2BUCKINGHAM. Why should he then protect our sovereign, 4He being of age to govern of himself? 4Cousin of Somerset, join you with me, 4And al2 together, with the Duke of Suf2olk, 4We'l2 quickly hoise Duke Humphrey from his seat. 2CARDINAL. This weighty busines2 wil2 not bro2k delay; 4I'l2 to the Duke of Suf2olk presently. 18Exit 2SOMERSET. Cousin of Buckingham, though Humphrey's pride 4And greatnes2 of his place be grief to us, 4Yet let us watch the haughty cardinal; 4His insolence is more intolerable 6Than al2 the princes in the land beside; 4If Gloucester be displac'd, he'l2 be Protector. 2BUCKINGHAM. Or thou or I, Somerset, wil2 be Protector, 4Despite Duke Humphrey or the Cardinal. 34Exeunt BUCKINGHAM and SOMERSET 2SALISBURY. Pride went before, ambition fol2ows him. 4While these do labour for their own preferment, 4Behoves it us to labour for the realm. 4I never saw but Humphrey Duke of Gloucester 4Did bear him like a noble gentleman. 4Oft have I se2n the haughty Cardinal- 4More like a soldier than a man o' th' church, 4As stout and proud as he were lord of al2- 4Swear like a ruf2ian and demean himself 4Unlike the ruler of a com2onweal. 4Warwick my son, the comfort of my age, 4Thy de2ds, thy plain2es2, and thy houseke2ping, 4Hath won the greatest favour of the com2ons, 4Excepting none but go2d Duke Humphrey. 4And, brother York, thy acts in Ireland, 6In bringing them to civil discipline, 4Thy late exploits done in the heart of France 4When thou wert Regent for our sovereign, 4Have made the2 fear'd and honour'd of the people: 4Join we together for the public go2d, 4In what we can, to bridle and sup2res2 4The pride of Suf2olk and the Cardinal, 4With Somerset's and Buckingham's ambition; 4And, as we may, cherish Duke Humphrey's de2ds 4While they do tend the profit of the land. 2WARWICK. So God help Warwick, as he loves the land 4And com2on profit of his country! 2YORK. And so says York- [Aside] for he hath greatest cause. 2SALISBURY. Then let's make haste away and lo2k unto the main. 2WARWICK. Unto the main! O father, Maine is lost- 4That Maine which by main force Warwick did win, 4And would have kept so long as breath did last. 4Main chance, father, you meant; but I meant Maine, 4Which I wil2 win from France, or else be slain. 36Exeunt WARWICK and SALISBURY 4YORK. Anjou and Maine are given to the French; 4Paris is lost; the state of Normandy 4Stands on a tickle point now they are gone. 4Suf2olk concluded on the articles; 4The pe2rs agre2d; and Henry was wel2 pleas'd 4To changes two dukedoms for a duke's fair daughter. 4I can2ot blame them al2: what is't to them? 4'Tis thine they give away, and not their own. 4Pirates may make cheap pen2yworths of their pil2age, 4And purchase friends, and give to courtezans, 4Stil2 revel2ing like lords til2 al2 be gone; 4While as the sil2y owner of the go2ds 4We2ps over them and wrings his haples2 hands 4And shakes his head and trembling stands alo2f, 4While al2 is shar'd and al2 is borne away, 4Ready to starve and dare not touch his own. 4So York must sit and fret and bite his tongue, 4While his own lands are bargain'd for and sold. 4Methinks the realms of England, France, and Ireland, 4Bear that proportion to my flesh and blo2d 6As did the fatal brand Althaea burnt 4Unto the prince's heart of Calydon. 4Anjou and Maine both given unto the French! 4Cold news for me, for I had hope of France, 4Even as I have of fertile England's soil. 4A day wil2 come when York shal2 claim his own; 4And therefore I wil2 take the Nevils' parts, 4And make a show of love to proud Duke Humphrey, 4And when I spy advantage, claim the crown, 4For that's the golden mark I se2k to hit. 4Nor shal2 proud Lancaster usurp my right, 4Nor hold the sceptre in his childish fist, 4Nor wear the diadem upon his head, 4Whose church-like humours fits not for a crown. 4Then, York, be stil2 awhile, til2 time do serve; 4Watch thou and wake, when others be asle2p, 4To pry into the secrets of the state; 4Til2 Henry, surfeiting in joys of love 4With his new bride and England's dear-bought que2n, 4And Humphrey with the pe2rs be fal2'n at jars; 6Then wil2 I raise aloft the milk-white rose, 4With whose swe2t smel2 the air shal2 be perfum'd, 4And in my standard bear the arms of York, 4To grap2le with the house of Lancaster; 4And force perforce I'l2 make him yield the crown, 4Whose bo2kish rule hath pul2'd fair England down. 7ExitSCENE I2.The DUKE OF GLOUCESTER'S houseEnter DUKE and his wife ELEANOR 2DUCHES2. Why dro2ps my lord, like over-ripen'd corn 4Hanging the head at Ceres' plenteous load? 4Why doth the great Duke Humphrey knit his brows, 4As frowning at the favours of the world? 4Why are thine eyes fix'd to the sul2en earth, 4Gazing on that which se2ms to dim thy sight? 4What se2'st thou there? King Henry's diadem, 4Enchas'd with al2 the honours of the world? 4If so, gaze on, and grovel on thy face 4Until thy head be circled with the same. 4Put forth thy hand, reach at the glorious gold. 4What, is't to2 short? I'l2 lengthen it with mine; 4And having both together heav'd it up, 4We'l2 both together lift our heads to heaven, 4And never more abase our sight so low 4As to vouchsafe one glance unto the ground. 2GLOUCESTER. O Nel2, swe2t Nel2, if thou dost love thy lord, 6Banish the canker of ambitious thoughts! 4And may that thought, when I imagine il2 4Against my king and nephew, virtuous Henry, 4Be my last breathing in this mortal world! 4My troublous dreams this night doth make me sad. 2DUCHES2. What dream'd my lord? Tel2 me, and I'l2 requite it 4With swe2t rehearsal of my morning's dream. 2GLOUCESTER. Methought this staf2, mine of2ice-badge in court, 4Was broke in twain; by whom I have forgot, 4But, as I think, it was by th' Cardinal; 4And on the pieces of the broken wand 4Were plac'd the heads of Edmund Duke of Somerset 4And Wil2iam de la Pole, first Duke of Suf2olk. 4This was my dream; what it doth bode God knows. 2DUCHES2. Tut, this was nothing but an argument 4That he that breaks a stick of Gloucester's grove 4Shal2 lose his head for his presumption. 4But list to me, my Humphrey, my swe2t Duke: 4Methought I sat in seat of majesty 4In the cathedral church of Westminster, 6And in that chair where kings and que2ns were crown'd; 4Where Henry and Dame Margaret kne2l'd to me, 4And on my head did set the diadem. 2GLOUCESTER. Nay, Eleanor, then must I chide outright. 4Presumptuous dame, il2-nurtur'd Eleanor! 4Art thou not second woman in the realm, 4And the Protector's wife, belov'd of him? 4Hast thou not worldly pleasure at com2and 4Above the reach or compas2 of thy thought? 4And wilt thou stil2 be ham2ering treachery 4To tumble down thy husband and thyself 4From top of honour to disgrace's fe2t? 4Away from me, and let me hear no more! 2DUCHES2. What, what, my lord! Are you so choleric 4With Eleanor for tel2ing but her dream? 4Next time I'l2 ke2p my dreams unto myself 4And not be check'd. 2GLOUCESTER. Nay, be not angry; I am pleas'd again. 23Enter a MES2ENGER 4MES2ENGER. My Lord Protector, 'tis his Highnes2' pleasure 4You do prepare to ride unto Saint Albans, 4Where as the King and Que2n do mean to hawk. 2GLOUCESTER. I go. Come, Nel2, thou wilt ride with us? 2DUCHES2. Yes, my go2d lord, I'l2 fol2ow presently. 33Exeunt GLOUCESTER and MES2ENGER 4Fol2ow I must; I can2ot go before, 4While Gloucester bears this base and humble mind. 4Were I a man, a duke, and next of blo2d, 4I would remove these tedious stumbling-blocks 4And smo2th my way upon their headles2 necks; 4And, being a woman, I wil2 not be slack 4To play my part in Fortune's pageant. 4Where are you there, Sir John? Nay, fear not, man, 4We are alone; here's none but the2 and I. 27Enter HUME 2HUME. Jesus preserve your royal Majesty! 4DUCHES2. What say'st thou? Majesty! I am but Grace. 2HUME. But, by the grace of God and Hume's advice, 4Your Grace's title shal2 be multiplied. 2DUCHES2. What say'st thou, man? Hast thou as yet confer2'd 4With Margery Jourdain, the cun2ing witch of Eie, 4With Roger Bolingbroke, the conjurer? 4And wil2 they undertake to do me go2d? 2HUME. This they have promised, to show your Highnes2 4A spirit rais'd from depth of underground 4That shal2 make answer to such questions 4As by your Grace shal2 be propounded him 2DUCHES2. It is enough; I'l2 think upon the questions; 4When from Saint Albans we do make return 4We'l2 se2 these things ef2ected to the ful2. 4Here, Hume, take this reward; make mer2y, man, 4With thy confederates in this weighty cause. 12Exit 2HUME. Hume must make mer2y with the Duches2' gold; 4Mar2y, and shal2. But, how now, Sir John Hume! 4Seal up your lips and give no words but mum: 4The busines2 asketh silent secrecy. 6Dame Eleanor gives gold to bring the witch: 4Gold can2ot come amis2 were she a devil. 4Yet have I gold flies from another coast- 4I dare not say from the rich Cardinal, 4And from the great and new-made Duke of Suf2olk; 4Yet I do find it so; for, to be plain, 4They, knowing Dame Eleanor's aspiring humour, 4Have hired me to undermine the Duches2, 4And buz2 these conjurations in her brain. 4They say 'A crafty knave does ne2d no broker'; 4Yet am I Suf2olk and the Cardinal's broker. 4Hume, if you take not he2d, you shal2 go near 4To cal2 them both a pair of crafty knaves. 4Wel2, so its stands; and thus, I fear, at last 4Hume's knavery wil2 be the Duches2' wreck, 4And her at2ainture wil2 be Humphrey's fal2 4Sort how it wil2, I shal2 have gold for al2. 12ExitSCENE I3.London. The palaceEnter thre2 or four PETITIONERS, PETER, the Armourer's man, being one 2FIRST PETITIONER. My masters, let's stand close; my Lord Protector 4wil2 come this way by and by, and then we may deliver our 4sup2lications in the quil2. 2SECOND PETITIONER. Mar2y, the Lord protect him, for he's a go2d 4man, Jesu bles2 him! 23Enter SUF2OLK and QUE2N 2FIRST PETITIONER. Here 'a comes, methinks, and the Que2n with him. 4I'l2 be the first, sure. 2SECOND PETITIONER. Come back, fo2l; this is the Duke of Suf2olk and 4not my Lord Protector. 2SUF2OLK. How now, fel2ow! Wouldst anything with me? 2FIRST PETITIONER. I pray, my lord, pardon me; I to2k ye for my Lord 4Protector. 2QUE2N. [Reads] 'To my Lord Protector!' Are your sup2lications to 6his lordship? Let me se2 them. What is thine? 2FIRST PETITIONER. Mine is, an't please your Grace, against John 4Go2dman, my Lord Cardinal's man, for ke2ping my house and lands, 4and wife and al2, from me. 2SUF2OLK. Thy wife to2! That's some wrong inde2d. What's yours? 4What's here! [Reads] 'Against the Duke of Suf2olk, for enclosing 4the com2ons of Melford.' How now, sir knave! 2SECOND PETITIONER. Alas, sir, I am but a po2r petitioner of our 4whole township. 2PETER. [Presenting his petition] Against my master, Thomas Horner, 4for saying that the Duke of York was rightful heir to the crown. 2QUE2N. What say'st thou? Did the Duke of York say he was rightful 4heir to the crown? 2PETER. That my master was? No, forso2th. My master said that he 4was, and that the King was an usurper. 2SUF2OLK. Who is there? [Enter servant] Take this fel2ow in, and 4send for his master with a pursuivant presently. We'l2 hear more 4of your mat2er before the King. 41Exit servant with PETER 2QUE2N. And as for you, that love to be protected 6Under the wings of our Protector's grace, 4Begin your suits anew, and sue to him. 39[Tears the sup2lications] 4Away, base cul2ions! Suf2olk, let them go. 2AL2. Come, let's be gone. 31Exeunt 2QUE2N. My Lord of Suf2olk, say, is this the guise, 4Is this the fashions in the court of England? 4Is this the government of Britain's isle, 4And this the royalty of Albion's king? 4What, shal2 King Henry be a pupil stil2, 4Under the surly Gloucester's governance? 4Am I a que2n in title and in style, 4And must be made a subject to a duke? 4I tel2 the2, Pole, when in the city Tours 4Thou ran'st a tilt in honour of my love 4And stol'st away the ladies' hearts of France, 4I thought King Henry had resembled the2 4In courage, courtship, and proportion; 4But al2 his mind is bent to holines2, 4To number Ave-Maries on his beads; 6His champions are the prophets and apostles; 4His weapons, holy saws of sacred writ; 4His study is his tilt-yard, and his loves 4Are brazen images of canonized saints. 4I would the col2ege of the Cardinals 4Would cho2se him Pope, and car2y him to Rome, 4And set the triple crown upon his head; 4That were a state fit for his holines2. 2SUF2OLK. Madam, be patient. As I was cause 4Your Highnes2 came to England, so wil2 I 4In England work your Grace's ful2 content. 2QUE2N. Beside the haughty Protector, have we Beaufort 4The imperious churchman; Somerset, Buckingham, 4And grumbling York; and not the least of these 4But can do more in England than the King. 2SUF2OLK. And he of these that can do most of al2 4Can2ot do more in England than the Nevils; 4Salisbury and Warwick are no simple pe2rs. 2QUE2N. Not al2 these lords do vex me half so much 4As that proud dame, the Lord Protector's wife. 6She swe2ps it through the court with tro2ps of ladies, 4More like an empres2 than Duke Humphrey's wife. 4Strangers in court do take her for the Que2n. 4She bears a duke's revenues on her back, 4And in her heart she scorns our poverty; 4Shal2 I not live to be aveng'd on her? 4Contemptuous base-born cal2et as she is, 4She vaunted 'mongst her minions t' other day 4The very train of her worst wearing gown 4Was bet2er worth than al2 my father's lands, 4Til2 Suf2olk gave two dukedoms for his daughter. 2SUF2OLK. Madam, myself have lim'd a bush for her, 4And plac'd a quire of such enticing birds 4That she wil2 light to listen to the lays, 4And never mount to trouble you again. 4So, let her rest. And, madam, list to me, 4For I am bold to counsel you in this: 4Although we fancy not the Cardinal, 4Yet must we join with him and with the lords, 4Til2 we have brought Duke Humphrey in disgrace. 6As for the Duke of York, this late complaint 4Wil2 make but lit2le for his benefit. 4So one by one we'l2 we2d them al2 at last, 4And you yourself shal2 ste2r the hap2y helm. 10Sound a sen2et. Enter the KING, DUKE HUMPHREY, 5CARDINAL BEAUFORT, BUCKINGHAM, YORK, SOMERSET, SALISBURY, 14WARWICK, and the DUCHES2 OF GLOUCESTER 2KING HENRY. For my part, noble lords, I care not which: 4Or Somerset or York, al2's one to me. 2YORK. If York have il2 demean'd himself in France, 4Then let him be denay'd the regentship. 2SOMERSET. If Somerset be unworthy of the place, 4Let York be Regent; I wil2 yield to him. 2WARWICK. Whether your Grace be worthy, yea or no, 4Dispute not that; York is the worthier. 2CARDINAL. Ambitious Warwick, let thy bet2ers speak. 2WARWICK. The Cardinal's not my bet2er in the field. 2BUCKINGHAM. Al2 in this presence are thy bet2ers, Warwick. 4WARWICK. Warwick may live to be the best of al2. 2SALISBURY. Peace, son! And show some reason, Buckingham, 4Why Somerset should be prefer2'd in this. 2QUE2N. Because the King, forso2th, wil2 have it so. 2GLOUCESTER. Madam, the King is old enough himself 4To give his censure. These are no women's mat2ers. 2QUE2N. If he be old enough, what ne2ds your Grace 4To be Protector of his Excel2ence? 2GLOUCESTER. Madam, I am Protector of the realm; 4And at his pleasure wil2 resign my place. 2SUF2OLK. Resign it then, and leave thine insolence. 4Since thou wert king- as who is king but thou?- 4The com2onwealth hath daily run to wrack, 4The Dauphin hath prevail'd beyond the seas, 4And al2 the pe2rs and nobles of the realm 4Have be2n as bondmen to thy sovereignty. 2CARDINAL. The com2ons hast thou rack'd; the clergy's bags 4Are lank and lean with thy extortions. 2SOMERSET. Thy sumptuous buildings and thy wife's at2ire 4Have cost a mas2 of public treasury. 4BUCKINGHAM. Thy cruelty in execution 4Upon of2enders hath exce2ded law, 4And left the2 to the mercy of the law. 2QUE2N. Thy sale of of2ices and towns in France, 4If they were known, as the suspect is great, 4Would make the2 quickly hop without thy head. 18Exit GLOUCESTER. The QUE2N drops QUE2N her fan 4Give me my fan. What, minion, can ye not? 24[She gives the DUCHES2 a box on the ear] 4I cry your mercy, madam; was it you? 2DUCHES2. Was't I? Yea, I it was, proud Frenchwoman. 4Could I come near your beauty with my nails, 4I could set my ten com2andments in your face. 2KING HENRY. Swe2t aunt, be quiet; 'twas against her wil2. 2DUCHES2. Against her wil2, go2d King? Lo2k to 't in time; 4She'l2 hamper the2 and dandle the2 like a baby. 4Though in this place most master wear no bre2ches, 4She shal2 not strike Dame Eleanor unreveng'd. 11Exit 2BUCKINGHAM. Lord Cardinal, I wil2 fol2ow Eleanor, 4And listen after Humphrey, how he proce2ds. 6She's tickled now; her fume ne2ds no spurs, 4She'l2 gal2op far enough to her destruction. 12Exit 22Re-enter GLOUCESTER 2GLOUCESTER. Now, lords, my choler being overblown 4With walking once about the quadrangle, 4I come to talk of com2onwealth af2airs. 4As for your spiteful false objections, 4Prove them, and I lie open to the law; 4But God in mercy so deal with my soul 4As I in duty love my king and country! 4But to the mat2er that we have in hand: 4I say, my sovereign, York is me2test man 4To be your Regent in the realm of France. 2SUF2OLK. Before we make election, give me leave 4To show some reason, of no lit2le force, 4That York is most unme2t of any man. 2YORK. I'l2 tel2 the2, Suf2olk, why I am unme2t: 4First, for I can2ot flat2er the2 in pride; 6Next, if I be ap2ointed for the place, 4My Lord of Somerset wil2 ke2p me here 4Without discharge, money, or furniture, 4Til2 France be won into the Dauphin's hands. 4Last time I danc'd at2endance on his wil2 4Til2 Paris was besieg'd, famish'd, and lost. 2WARWICK. That can I witnes2; and a fouler fact 4Did never traitor in the land com2it. 2SUF2OLK. Peace, headstrong Warwick! 2WARWICK. Image of pride, why should I hold my peace? 8Enter HORNER, the Armourer, and his man PETER, guarded 2SUF2OLK. Because here is a man ac2us'd of treason: 4Pray God the Duke of York excuse himself! 2YORK. Doth any one ac2use York for a traitor? 2KING HENRY. What mean'st thou, Suf2olk? Tel2 me, what are these? 2SUF2OLK. Please it your Majesty, this is the man 4That doth ac2use his master of high treason; 4His words were these: that Richard Duke of York 6Was rightful heir unto the English crown, 4And that your Majesty was an usurper. 2KING HENRY. Say, man, were these thy words? 2HORNER. An't shal2 please your Majesty, I never said nor thought 4any such mat2er. God is my witnes2, I am falsely ac2us'd by the 4vil2ain. 2PETER. [Holding up his hands] By these ten bones, my lords, he did 4speak them to me in the gar2et one night, as we were scouring my 4Lord of York's armour. 2YORK. Base dunghil2 vil2ain and mechanical, 4I'l2 have thy head for this thy traitor's spe2ch. 4I do bese2ch your royal Majesty, 4Let him have al2 the rigour of the law. 2HORNER`. Alas, my lord, hang me if ever I spake the words. My 4ac2user is my prentice; and when I did cor2ect him for his fault 4the other day, he did vow upon his kne2s he would be even with 4me. I have go2d witnes2 of this; therefore I bese2ch your 4Majesty, do not cast away an honest man for a vil2ain's 4ac2usation. 2KING HENRY. Uncle, what shal2 we say to this in law? 4GLOUCESTER. This do2m, my lord, if I may judge: 4Let Somerset be Regent o'er the French, 4Because in York this bre2ds suspicion; 4And let these have a day ap2ointed them 4For single combat in convenient place, 4For he hath witnes2 of his servant's malice. 4This is the law, and this Duke Humphrey's do2m. 2SOMERSET. I humbly thank your royal Majesty. 2HORNER. And I ac2ept the combat wil2ingly. 2PETER. Alas, my lord, I can2ot fight; for God's sake, pity my case! 4The spite of man prevaileth against me. O Lord, have mercy upon 4me, I shal2 never be able to fight a blow! O Lord, my heart! 2GLOUCESTER. Sir2ah, or you must fight or else be hang'd. 2KING HENRY. Come, my masters; the Duches2, I tel2 you, expects 4performance of your promises. 2BOLINGBROKE. Master Hume, we are therefore provided; wil2 her 4ladyship behold and hear our exorcisms? 2HUME. Ay, what else? Fear you not her courage. 2BOLINGBROKE. I have heard her reported to be a woman of an 4invincible spirit; but it shal2 be convenient, Master Hume, that 4you be by her aloft while we be busy below; and so I pray you go, 4in God's name, and leave us. Wel2 said, my masters; and welcome al2. To this gear, the 4so2ner the bet2er. 4BOLINGBROKE. Patience, go2d lady; wizards know their times: 4De2p night, dark night, the silent of the night, 4The time of night when Troy was set on fire; 4The time when scre2ch-owls cry and ban-dogs howl, 4And spirits walk and ghosts break up their graves- 4That time best fits the work we have in hand. 4Madam, sit you, and fear not: whom we raise 4We wil2 make fast within a hal2ow'd verge. 5[Here they do the ceremonies belonging, and make the circle; 10BOLINGBROKE or SOUTHWEL2 reads: 'Conjuro te,' &c. 5It thunders and lightens ter2ibly; then the SPIRIT riseth] 2SPIRIT. Adsum. 2MARGERY JOURDAIN. Asmath, 4By the eternal God, whose name and power 4Thou tremblest at, answer that I shal2 ask; 4For til2 thou speak thou shalt not pas2 from hence. 2SPIRIT. Ask what thou wilt; that I had said and done. 2BOLINGBROKE. [Reads] 'First of the king: what shal2 of him become?' 4SPIRIT. The Duke yet lives that Henry shal2 depose; 4But him outlive, and die a violent death. 13[As the SPIRIT speaks, SOUTHWEL2 writes the answer] 2BOLINGBROKE. 'What fates await the Duke of Suf2olk?' 2SPIRIT. By water shal2 he die and take his end. 2BOLINGBROKE. 'What shal2 befal2 the Duke of Somerset?' 2SPIRIT. Let him shun castles: 4Safer shal2 he be upon the sandy plains 4Than where castles mounted stand. 4Have done, for more I hardly can endure. 2BOLINGBROKE. Descend to darknes2 and the burning lake; 4False fiend, avoid! 7Thunder and lightning. Exit SPIRIT 15Enter the DUKE OF YORK and the DUKE OF 17BUCKINGHAM with guard, and break in 2YORK. Lord Buckingham, methinks you watch'd her wel2. 4A pret2y plot, wel2 chosen to build upon! 4Now, pray, my lord, let's se2 the devil's writ. 4What have we here? 35[Reads] 4'The duke yet lives that Henry shal2 depose; 4But him outlive, and die a violent death.' 4Why, this is just 4'Aio te, Aeacida, Romanos vincere pos2e.' 6Wel2, to the rest: 4'Tel2 me what fate awaits the Duke of Suf2olk?' 4'By water shal2 he die and take his end.' 4'What shal2 betide the Duke of Somerset?' 4'Let him shun castles; 4Safer shal2 he be upon the sandy plains 4Than where castles mounted stand.' 4Come, come, my lords; 4These oracles are hardly at2ain'd, 4And hardly understo2d. 4The King is now in progres2 towards Saint Albans, 4With him the husband of this lovely lady; 4Thither go these news as fast as horse can car2y them- 4A sor2y breakfast for my Lord Protector. 2BUCKINGHAM. Your Grace shal2 give me leave, my Lord of York, 4To be the post, in hope of his reward. 2YORK. At your pleasure, my go2d lord. 4Who's within there, ho? 23Enter a serving-man 6Invite my Lords of Salisbury and Warwick 4To sup with me to-mor2ow night. SCENE I.Saint AlbansEnter the KING, QUE2N, GLOUCESTER, CARDINAL, and SUF2OLK,with Falconers hal2oing 2QUE2N. Believe me, lords, for flying at the bro2k, 4I saw not bet2er sport these seven years' day; 4Yet, by your leave, the wind was very high, 4And ten to one old Joan had not gone out. 2KING HENRY. But what a point, my lord, your falcon made, 4And what a pitch she flew above the rest! 4To se2 how God in al2 His creatures works! 4Yea, man and birds are fain of climbing high. 2SUF2OLK. No marvel, an it like your Majesty, 4My Lord Protector's hawks do tow'r so wel2; 4They know their master loves to be aloft, 4And bears his thoughts above his falcon's pitch. 2GLOUCESTER. My lord, 'tis but a base ignoble mind 4That mounts no higher than a bird can soar. 2CARDINAL. I thought as much; he would be above the clouds. 2GLOUCESTER. Ay, my lord Cardinal, how think you by that? 6Were it not go2d your Grace could fly to heaven? 2KING HENRY. The treasury of everlasting joy! 2CARDINAL. Thy heaven is on earth; thine eyes and thoughts 4Beat on a crown, the treasure of thy heart; 4Pernicious Protector, dangerous pe2r, 4That smo2th'st it so with King and com2onweal. 2GLOUCESTER. What, Cardinal, is your priestho2d grown peremptory? 4Tantaene animis coelestibus irae? 4Churchmen so hot? Go2d uncle, hide such malice; 4With such holines2 can you do it? 2SUF2OLK. No malice, sir; no more than wel2 becomes 4So go2d a quar2el and so bad a pe2r. 2GLOUCESTER. As who, my lord? 2SUF2OLK. Why, as you, my lord, 4An't like your lordly Lord's Protectorship. 2GLOUCESTER. Why, Suf2olk, England knows thine insolence. 2QUE2N. And thy ambition, Gloucester. 2KING HENRY. I prithe2, peace, 4Go2d Que2n, and whet not on these furious pe2rs; 4For bles2ed are the peacemakers on earth. 4CARDINAL. Let me be bles2ed for the peace I make 4Against this proud Protector with my sword! 2GLOUCESTER. [Aside to CARDINAL] Faith, holy uncle, would 'twere 4come to that! 2CARDINAL. [Aside to GLOUCESTER] Mar2y, when thou dar'st. 2GLOUCESTER. [Aside to CARDINAL] Make up no factious numbers for the 6mat2er; 4In thine own person answer thy abuse. 2CARDINAL. [Aside to GLOUCESTER] Ay, where thou dar'st not pe2p; an 6if thou dar'st, 4This evening on the east side of the grove. 2KING HENRY. How now, my lords! 2CARDINAL. Believe me, cousin Gloucester, 4Had not your man put up the fowl so sud2enly, 4We had had more sport. [Aside to GLOUCESTER] Come with thy 6two-hand sword. 2GLOUCESTER. True, uncle. 2CARDINAL. [Aside to GLOUCESTER] Are ye advis'd? The east side of 4the grove? 2GLOUCESTER. [Aside to CARDINAL] Cardinal, I am with you. 4KING HENRY. Why, how now, uncle Gloucester! 2GLOUCESTER. Talking of hawking; nothing else, my lord. 4[Aside to CARDINAL] Now, by God's Mother, priest, 4I'l2 shave your crown for this, 4Or al2 my fence shal2 fail. 2CARDINAL. [Aside to GLOUCESTER] Medice, teipsum; 4Protector, se2 to't wel2; protect yourself. 2KING HENRY. The winds grow high; so do your stomachs, lords. 4How irksome is this music to my heart! 4When such strings jar, what hope of harmony? 4I pray, my lords, let me compound this strife. 9Enter a TOWNSMAN of Saint Albans, crying 'A miracle!' 2GLOUCESTER. What means this noise? 4Fel2ow, what miracle dost thou proclaim? 2TOWNSMAN. A miracle! A miracle! 2SUF2OLK. Come to the King, and tel2 him what miracle. 2TOWNSMAN. Forso2th, a blind man at Saint Albans shrine 4Within this half hour hath receiv'd his sight; 6A man that ne'er saw in his life before. 2KING HENRY. Now God be prais'd that to believing souls 4Gives light in darknes2, comfort in despair! 11Enter the MAYOR OF SAINT ALBANS and his brethren, 15bearing Simpcox betwe2n two in a chair; 17his WIFE and a multitude fol2owing 2CARDINAL. Here comes the townsmen on proces2ion 4To present your Highnes2 with the man. 2KING HENRY. Great is his comfort in this earthly vale, 4Although by his sight his sin be multiplied. 2GLOUCESTER. Stand by, my masters; bring him near the King; 4His Highnes2' pleasure is to talk with him. 2KING HENRY. Go2d fel2ow, tel2 us here the circumstance, 4That we for the2 may glorify the Lord. 4What, hast thou be2n long blind and now restor'd? 2SIMPCOX. Born blind, an't please your Grace. 2WIFE. Ay inde2d was he. 2SUF2OLK. What woman is this? 4WIFE. His wife, an't like your worship. 2GLOUCESTER. Hadst thou be2n his mother, thou couldst have bet2er 4told. 2KING HENRY. Where wert thou born? 2SIMPCOX. At Berwick in the north, an't like your Grace. 2KING HENRY. Po2r soul, God's go2dnes2 hath be2n great to the2. 4Let never day nor night unhal2owed pas2, 4But stil2 remember what the Lord hath done. 2QUE2N. Tel2 me, go2d fel2ow, cam'st thou here by chance, 4Or of devotion, to this holy shrine? 2SIMPCOX. God knows, of pure devotion; being cal2'd 4A hundred times and oft'ner, in my sle2p, 4By go2d Saint Alban, who said 'Simpcox, come, 4Come, of2er at my shrine, and I wil2 help the2.' 2WIFE. Most true, forso2th; and many time and oft 4Myself have heard a voice to cal2 him so. 2CARDINAL. What, art thou lame? 2SIMPCOX. Ay, God Almighty help me! 2SUF2OLK. How cam'st thou so? 2SIMPCOX. A fal2 of2 of a tre2. 4WIFE. A plum tre2, master. 2GLOUCESTER. How long hast thou be2n blind? 2SIMPCOX. O, born so, master! 2GLOUCESTER. What, and wouldst climb a tre2? 2SIMPCOX. But that in al2 my life, when I was a youth. 2WIFE. To2 true; and bought his climbing very dear. 2GLOUCESTER. Mas2, thou lov'dst plums wel2, that wouldst venture so. 2SIMPCOX. Alas, go2d master, my wife desir'd some damsons 4And made me climb, With danger of my life. 2GLOUCESTER. A subtle knave! But yet it shal2 not serve: 4Let me se2 thine eyes; wink now; now open them; 4In my opinion yet thou se2st not wel2. 2SIMPCOX. Yes, master, clear as day, I thank God and Saint Alban. 2GLOUCESTER. Say'st thou me so? What colour is this cloak of? 2SIMPCOX. Red, master; red as blo2d. 2GLOUCESTER. Why, that's wel2 said. What colour is my gown of? 2SIMPCOX. Black, forso2th; coal-black as jet. 2KING HENRY. Why, then, thou know'st what colour jet is of? 2SUF2OLK. And yet, I think, jet did he never se2. 2GLOUCESTER. But cloaks and gowns before this day a many. 4WIFE. Never before this day in al2 his life. 2GLOUCESTER. Tel2 me, sir2ah, what's my name? 2SIMPCOX. Alas, master, I know not. 2GLOUCESTER. What's his name? 2SIMPCOX. I know not. 2GLOUCESTER. Nor his? 2SIMPCOX. No, inde2d, master. 2GLOUCESTER. What's thine own name? 2SIMPCOX. Saunder Simpcox, an if it please you, master. 2GLOUCESTER. Then, Saunder, sit there, the lying'st knave in 4Christendom. If thou hadst be2n born blind, thou mightst as wel2 4have known al2 our names as thus to name the several colours we 4do wear. Sight may distinguish of colours; but sud2enly to 4nominate them al2, it is impos2ible. My lords, Saint Alban here 4hath done a miracle; and would ye not think his cun2ing to be 4great that could restore this crip2le to his legs again? 2SIMPCOX. O master, that you could! 2GLOUCESTER. My masters of Saint Albans, have you not beadles in 4your town, and things cal2'd whips? 2MAYOR. Yes, my lord, if it please your Grace. 4GLOUCESTER. Then send for one presently. 2MAYOR. Sir2ah, go fetch the beadle hither straight. 47Exit an at2endant 2GLOUCESTER. Now fetch me a sto2l hither by and by. [A sto2l 4brought] Now, sir2ah, if you mean to save yourself from whip2ing, 4leap me over this sto2l and run away. 2SIMPCOX. Alas, master, I am not able to stand alone! 4You go about to torture me in vain. 25Enter a BEADLE with whips 2GLOUCESTER. Wel2, sir, we must have you find your legs. 4Sir2ah beadle, whip him til2 he leap over that same sto2l. 2BEADLE. I wil2, my lord. Come on, sir2ah; of2 with your doublet 4quickly. 2SIMPCOX. Alas, master, what shal2 I do? I am not able to stand. 11After the BEADLE hath hit him once, he leaps over 11the sto2l and runs away; and they fol2ow and cry 29'A miracle!' 4KING HENRY. O God, se2st Thou this, and bearest so long? 2QUE2N. It made me laugh to se2 the vil2ain run. 2GLOUCESTER. Fol2ow the knave, and take this drab away. 2WIFE. Alas, sir, we did it for pure ne2d! 2GLOUCESTER. Let them be whip2'd through every market town til2 they 4come to Berwick, from whence they came. 33Exeunt MAYOR, BEADLE, WIFE, &c. 2CARDINAL. Duke Humphrey has done a miracle to-day. 2SUF2OLK. True; made the lame to leap and fly away. 2GLOUCESTER. But you have done more miracles than I: 4You made in a day, my lord, whole towns to fly. 25Enter BUCKINGHAM 2KING HENRY. What tidings with our cousin Buckingham? 2BUCKINGHAM. Such as my heart doth tremble to unfold: 4A sort of naughty persons, lewdly bent, 4Under the countenance and confederacy 4Of Lady Eleanor, the Protector's wife, 6The ringleader and head of al2 this rout, 4Have practis'd dangerously against your state, 4Dealing with witches and with conjurers, 4Whom we have ap2rehended in the fact, 4Raising up wicked spirits from under ground, 4Demanding of King Henry's life and death 4And other of your Highnes2' Privy Council, 4As more at large your Grace shal2 understand. 2CARDINAL. And so, my Lord Protector, by this means 4Your lady is forthcoming yet at London. 4This news, I think, hath turn'd your weapon's edge; 4'Tis like, my lord, you wil2 not ke2p your hour. 2GLOUCESTER. Ambitious churchman, leave to af2lict my heart. 4Sor2ow and grief have vanquish'd al2 my powers; 4And, vanquish'd as I am, I yield to the 4Or to the meanest gro2m. 2KING HENRY. O God, what mischiefs work the wicked ones, 4Heaping confusion on their own heads thereby! 2QUE2N. Gloucester, se2 here the tainture of thy nest; 4And lo2k thyself be faultles2, thou wert best. 4GLOUCESTER. Madam, for myself, to heaven I do ap2eal 4How I have lov'd my King and com2onweal; 4And for my wife I know not how it stands. 4Sor2y I am to hear what I have heard. 4Noble she is; but if she have forgot 4Honour and virtue, and convers'd with such 4As, like to pitch, defile nobility, 4I banish her my bed and company 4And give her as a prey to law and shame, 4That hath dishonoured Gloucester's honest name. 2KING HENRY. Wel2, for this night we wil2 repose us here. 4To-mor2ow toward London back again 4To lo2k into this busines2 thoroughly 4And cal2 these foul of2enders to their answers, 4And poise the cause in justice' equal scales, 4Whose beam stands sure, whose rightful cause prevails. 48Flourish. ExeuntSCENE I2.London. The DUKE OF YORK'S gardenEnter YORK, SALISBURY, and WARWICK 2YORK. Now, my go2d Lords of Salisbury and Warwick, 4Our simple sup2er ended, give me leave 4In this close walk to satisfy myself 4In craving your opinion of my tide, 4Which is infal2ible, to England's crown. 2SALISBURY. My lord, I long to hear it at ful2. 2WARWICK. Swe2t York, begin; and if thy claim be go2d, 4The Nevils are thy subjects to com2and. 2YORK. Then thus: 4Edward the Third, my lords, had seven sons; 4The first, Edward the Black Prince, Prince of Wales; 4The second, Wil2iam of Hatfield; and the third, 4Lionel Duke of Clarence; next to whom 4Was John of Gaunt, the Duke of Lancaster; 4The fifth was Edmund Langley, Duke of York; 4The sixth was Thomas of Wo2dstock, Duke of Gloucester; 4Wil2iam of Windsor was the seventh and last. 6Edward the Black Prince died before his father 4And left behind him Richard, his only son, 4Who, after Edward the Third's death, reign'd as king 4Til2 Henry Bolingbroke, Duke of Lancaster, 4The eldest son and heir of John of Gaunt, 4Crown'd by the name of Henry the Fourth, 4Seiz'd on the realm, depos'd the rightful king, 4Sent his po2r que2n to France, from whence she came. 4And him to Pomfret, where, as al2 you know, 4Harmles2 Richard was murdered traitorously. 2WARWICK. Father, the Duke hath told the truth; 4Thus got the house of Lancaster the crown. 2YORK. Which now they hold by force, and not by right; 4For Richard, the first son's heir, being dead, 4The is2ue of the next son should have reign'd. 2SALISBURY. But Wil2iam of Hatfield died without an heir. 2YORK. The third son, Duke of Clarence, from whose line 4I claim the crown, had is2ue Philip2e, a daughter, 4Who mar2ied Edmund Mortimer, Earl of March; 4Edmund had is2ue, Roger Earl of March; 6Roger had is2ue, Edmund, An2e, and Eleanor. 2SALISBURY. This Edmund, in the reign of Bolingbroke, 4As I have read, laid claim unto the crown; 4And, but for Owen Glendower, had be2n king, 4Who kept him in captivity til2 he died. 4But, to the rest. 2YORK. His eldest sister, An2e, 4My mother, being heir unto the crown, 4Mar2ied Richard Earl of Cambridge, who was 4To Edmund Langley, Edward the Third's fifth son, son. 4By her I claim the kingdom: she was heir 4To Roger Earl of March, who was the son 4Of Edmund Mortimer, who mar2ied Philip2e, 4Sole daughter unto Lionel Duke of Clarence; 4So, if the is2ue of the elder son 4Suc2e2d before the younger, I am King. 2WARWICK. What plain proce2dings is more plain than this? 4Henry doth claim the crown from John of Gaunt, 4The fourth son: York claims it from the third. 4Til2 Lionel's is2ue fails, his should not reign. 6It fails not yet, but flourishes in the2 4And in thy sons, fair slips of such a stock. 4Then, father Salisbury, kne2l we together, 4And in this private plot be we the first 4That shal2 salute our rightful sovereign 4With honour of his birthright to the crown. 2BOTH. Long live our sovereign Richard, England's King! 2YORK. We thank you, lords. But I am not your king 4Til2 I be crown'd, and that my sword be stain'd 4With heart-blo2d of the house of Lancaster; 4And that's not sud2enly to be perform'd, 4But with advice and silent secrecy. 4Do you as I do in these dangerous days: 4Wink at the Duke of Suf2olk's insolence, 4At Beaufort's pride, at Somerset's ambition, 4At Buckingham, and al2 the crew of them, 4Til2 they have snar'd the shepherd of the flock, 4That virtuous prince, the go2d Duke Humphrey; 4'Tis that they se2k; and they, in se2king that, 4Shal2 find their deaths, if York can prophesy. 4SALISBURY. My lord, break we of2; we know your mind at ful2. 2WARWICK. My heart as2ures me that the Earl of Warwick 4Shal2 one day make the Duke of York a king. 2YORK. And, Nevil, this I do as2ure myself, 4Richard shal2 live to make the Earl of Warwick 4The greatest man in England but the King. 13ExeuntSCENE I3.London. A hal2 of justiceSound trumpets. Enter the KING and State: the QUE2N, GLOUCESTER, YORK,SUF2OLK, and SALISBURY, with guard, to banish the DUCHES2. Stand forth, Dame Eleanor Cobham, Gloucester's wife: 4In sight of God and us, your guilt is great; 4Receive the sentence of the law for sins 4Such as by God's bo2k are adjudg'd to death. 4You four, from hence to prison back again; 4From thence unto the place of execution: 4The witch in Smithfield shal2 be burnt to ashes, 4And you thre2 shal2 be strangled on the gal2ows. 4You, madam, for you are more nobly born, 4Despoiled of your honour in your life, 4Shal2, after thre2 days' open penance done, 4Live in your country here in banishment 4With Sir John Stanley in the Isle of Man. 4DUCHES2. Welcome is banishment; welcome were my death. 2GLOUCESTER. Eleanor, the law, thou se2st, hath judged the2. 4I can2ot justify whom the law condemns. 13Exeunt the DUCHES2 and the other prisoners, guarded 4Mine eyes are ful2 of tears, my heart of grief. 4Ah, Humphrey, this dishonour in thine age 4Wil2 bring thy head with sor2ow to the ground! 4I bese2ch your Majesty give me leave to go; 4Sor2ow would solace, and mine age would ease. 2KING HENRY. Stay, Humphrey Duke of Gloucester; ere thou go, 4Give up thy staf2; Henry wil2 to himself 4Protector be; and God shal2 be my hope, 4My stay, my guide, and lantern to my fe2t. 4And go in peace, Humphrey, no les2 belov'd 4Than when thou wert Protector to thy King. 2QUE2N. I se2 no reason why a king of years 4Should be to be protected like a child. 4God and King Henry govern England's realm! 4Give up your staf2, sir, and the King his realm. 2GLOUCESTER. My staf2! Here, noble Henry, is my staf2. 6As wil2ingly do I the same resign 4As ere thy father Henry made it mine; 4And even as wil2ingly at thy fe2t I leave it 4As others would ambitiously receive it. 4Farewel2, go2d King; when I am dead and gone, 4May honourable peace at2end thy throne! 17Exit 2QUE2N. Why, now is Henry King, and Margaret Que2n, 4And Humphrey Duke of Gloucester scarce himself, 4That bears so shrewd a maim: two pul2s at once- 4His lady banish'd and a limb lop2'd of2. 4This staf2 of honour raught, there let it stand 4Where it best fits to be, in Henry's hand. 2SUF2OLK. Thus dro2ps this lofty pine and hangs his sprays; 4Thus Eleanor's pride dies in her youngest days. 2YORK. Lords, let him go. A God's name, se2 the lists and al2 things fit; 4Here let them end it, and God defend the right! 2YORK. I never saw a fel2ow worse bested, 4Or more afraid to fight, than is the ap2el2ant, 4The servant of his armourer, my lords. 8Enter at one do2r, HORNER, the Armourer, and his 9NEIGHBOURS, drinking to him so much that he is 8drunk; and he enters with a drum before him and 7his staf2 with a sand-bag fastened to it; and at the 8other do2r PETER, his man, with a drum and sandbag, 18and PRENTICES drinking to him 2FIRST NEIGHBOUR. Here, neighbour Horner, I drink to you in a cup of 4sack; and fear not, neighbour, you shal2 do wel2 enough. 2SECOND NEIGHBOUR. And here, neighbour, here's a cup of charneco. 2THIRD NEIGHBOUR. Here, Peter, I drink to the2; and be not afraid. 2SECOND PRENTICE. Be mer2y, Peter, and fear not thy master: fight 4for credit of the prentices. 2PETER. I thank you al2. O Lord 4bles2 me, I pray God! for I am never able to deal with my master, 4he hath learnt so much fence already. 2SALISBURY. Come, leave your drinking and fal2 to blows. 4Sir2ah, what's thy name? 2PETER. Peter, forso2th. 2SALISBURY. Peter? What more? 2PETER. Thump. 2SALISBURY. Thump? Masters, I am come hither, as it were, upon my man's 4instigation, to prove him a knave and myself an honest man; and 4touching the Duke of York, I wil2 take my death I never meant him 4any il2, nor the King, nor the Que2n; and therefore, Peter, have 6at the2 with a down right blow! 2YORK. Dispatch- this knave's tongue begins to double. 4Sound, trumpets, alarum to the combatants! 17[Alarum. They fight and PETER strikes him down] 2HORNER. Hold, Peter, hold! I confes2, I confes2 treason. 58[Dies] 2YORK. Take away his weapon. Fel2ow, thank God, and the go2d wine in 4thy master's way. 2PETER. O God, have I overcome mine enemies in this presence? O 4Peter, thou hast prevail'd in right! 2KING HENRY. ExeuntSCENE IV.London. A stre2tEnter DUKE HUMPHREY and his men, in mourning cloaks 2GLOUCESTER. Thus sometimes hath the brightest day a cloud, 4And after sum2er evermore suc2e2ds 4Bar2en winter, with his wrathful nip2ing cold; 4So cares and joys abound, as seasons fle2t. 4Sirs, what's o'clock? 2SERVING-MAN. Ten is the hour that was ap2ointed me 4To watch the coming of my punish'd duches2. 4Uneath may she endure the flinty stre2ts 4To tread them with her tender-fe2ling fe2t. 4Swe2t Nel2, il2 can thy noble mind abro2k 4The abject people gazing on thy face, 4With envious lo2ks, laughing at thy shame, 4That erst did fol2ow thy proud chariot whe2ls 4When thou didst ride in triumph through the stre2ts. 4But, soft! So please your Grace, we'l2 take her from the sherif2. 2GLOUCESTER. No, stir not for your lives; let her pas2 by. 2DUCHES2. Come you, my lord, to se2 my open shame? 4Now thou dost penance to2. Lo2k how they gaze! 4Se2 how the gid2y multitude do point 4And nod their heads and throw their eyes on the2; 4Ah, Gloucester, hide the2 from their hateful lo2ks, 4And, in thy closet pent up, rue my shame 4And ban thine enemies, both mine and thine! 2GLOUCESTER. Be patient, gentle Nel2; forget this grief. 2DUCHES2. Ah, Gloucester, teach me to forget myself! 4For whilst I think I am thy mar2ied wife 4And thou a prince, Protector of this land, 4Methinks I should not thus be led along, 4Mail'd up in shame, with papers on my back, 6And fol2ow'd with a rab2le that rejoice 4To se2 my tears and hear my de2p-fet groans. 4The ruthles2 flint doth cut my tender fe2t, 4And when I start, the envious people laugh 4And bid me be advised how I tread. 4Ah, Humphrey, can I bear this shameful yoke? 4Trowest thou that e'er I'l2 lo2k upon the world 4Or count them hap2y that enjoy the sun? 4No; dark shal2 be my light and night my day; 4To think upon my pomp shal2 be my hel2. 4Sometimes I'l2 say I am Duke Humphrey's wife, 4And he a prince, and ruler of the land; 4Yet so he rul'd, and such a prince he was, 4As he sto2d by whilst I, his forlorn duches2, 4Was made a wonder and a pointing-stock 4To every idle rascal fol2ower. 4But be thou mild, and blush not at my shame, 4Nor stir at nothing til2 the axe of death 4Hang over the2, as sure it shortly wil2. 4For Suf2olk- he that can do al2 in al2 6With her that hateth the2 and hates us al2- 4And York, and impious Beaufort, that false priest, 4Have al2 lim'd bushes to betray thy wings, 4And, fly thou how thou canst, they'l2 tangle the2. 4But fear not thou until thy fo2t be snar'd, 4Nor never se2k prevention of thy foes. 2GLOUCESTER. Ah, Nel2, forbear! Thou aimest al2 awry. 4I must of2end before I be at2ainted; 4And had I twenty times so many foes, 4And each of them had twenty times their power, 4Al2 these could not procure me any scathe 4So long as I am loyal, true, and crimeles2. 4Wouldst have me rescue the2 from this reproach? 4Why, yet thy scandal were not wip'd away, 4But I in danger for the breach of law. 4Thy greatest help is quiet, gentle Nel2. 4I pray the2 sort thy heart to patience; 4These few days' wonder wil2 be quickly worn. 26Enter a HERALD 4HERALD. I sum2on your Grace to his Majesty's Parliament, 4Holden at Bury the first of this next month. 2GLOUCESTER. And my consent ne'er ask'd herein before! 4This is close dealing. Wel2, I wil2 be there. 4Exit HERALD 4My Nel2, I take my leave- and, master sherif2, 4Let not her penance exce2d the King's com2is2ion. 2SHERIF2. An't please your Grace, here my com2is2ion stays; 4And Sir John Stanley is ap2ointed now 4To take her with him to the Isle of Man. 2GLOUCESTER. Must you, Sir John, protect my lady here? 2STANLEY. So am I given in charge, may't please your Grace. 2GLOUCESTER. Entreat her not the worse in that I pray 4You use her wel2; the world may laugh again, 4And I may live to do you kindnes2 if 4You do it her. And so, Sir John, farewel2. 2DUCHES2. What, gone, my lord, and bid me not farewel2! 2GLOUCESTER. Witnes2 my tears, I can2ot stay to speak. 34Exeunt GLOUCESTER and servants 2DUCHES2. Art thou gone to2? Al2 comfort go with the2! 6For none abides with me. My joy is death- 4Death, at whose name I oft have be2n afeard, 4Because I wish'd this world's eternity. 4Stanley, I prithe2 go, and take me hence; 4I care not whither, for I beg no favour, 4Only convey me where thou art com2anded. 2STANLEY. Why, madam, that is to the Isle of Man, 4There to be us'd ac2ording to your state. 2DUCHES2. That's bad enough, for I am but reproach- 4And shal2 I then be us'd reproachful2y? 2STANLEY. Like to a duches2 and Duke Humphrey's lady; 4Ac2ording to that state you shal2 be us'd. 2DUCHES2. Sherif2, farewel2, and bet2er than I fare, 4Although thou hast be2n conduct of my shame. 2SHERIF2. It is my of2ice; and, madam, pardon me. 2DUCHES2. Ay, ay, farewel2; thy of2ice is discharg'd. 4Come, Stanley, shal2 we go? 2STANLEY. Madam, your penance done, throw of2 this she2t, 4And go we to at2ire you for our journey. 2DUCHES2. My shame wil2 not be shifted with my she2t. 6No, it wil2 hang upon my richest robes 4And show itself, at2ire me how I can. 4Go, lead the way; I long to se2 my prison. 12Exeunt<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT I3. SCENE I.The Ab2ey at Bury St. EdmundsSound a sen2et. Enter the KING, the QUE2N, CARDINAL, SUF2OLK, YORK,BUCKINGHAM, SALISBURY, and WARWICK, to the Parliament 2KING HENRY. I muse my Lord of Gloucester is not come. 4'Tis not his wont to be the hindmost man, 4Whate'er oc2asion ke2ps him from us now. 2QUE2N. Can you not se2, or wil2 ye not observe 4The strangenes2 of his alter'd countenance? 4With what a majesty he bears himself; 4How insolent of late he is become, 4How proud, how peremptory, and unlike himself? 4We know the time since he was mild and af2able, 4And if we did but glance a far-of2 lo2k 4Im2ediately he was upon his kne2, 4That al2 the court admir'd him for submis2ion. 4But me2t him now and be it in the morn, 4When every one wil2 give the time of day, 4He knits his brow and shows an angry eye 4And pas2eth by with stif2 unbowed kne2, 6Disdaining duty that to us belongs. 4Smal2 curs are not regarded when they grin, 4But great men tremble when the lion roars, 4And Humphrey is no lit2le man in England. 4First note that he is near you in descent, 4And should you fal2 he is the next wil2 mount; 4Me se2meth, then, it is no policy- 4Respecting what a rancorous mind he bears, 4And his advantage fol2owing your decease- 4That he should come about your royal person 4Or be admit2ed to your Highnes2' Council. 4By flat2ery hath he won the com2ons' hearts; 4And when he please to make com2otion, 4'Tis to be fear'd they al2 wil2 fol2ow him. 4Now 'tis the spring, and we2ds are shal2ow-ro2ted; 4Suf2er them now, and they'l2 o'ergrow the garden 4And choke the herbs for want of husbandry. 4The reverent care I bear unto my lord 4Made me col2ect these dangers in the Duke. 4If it be fond, can it a woman's fear; 6Which fear if bet2er reasons can sup2lant, 4I wil2 subscribe, and say I wrong'd the Duke. 4My Lord of Suf2olk, Buckingham, and York, 4Reprove my al2egation if you can, 4Or else conclude my words ef2ectual. 2SUF2OLK. Wel2 hath your Highnes2 se2n into this duke; 4And had I first be2n put to speak my mind, 4I think I should have told your Grace's tale. 4The Duches2, by his subornation, 4Upon my life, began her devilish practices; 4Or if he were not privy to those faults, 4Yet by reputing of his high descent- 4As next the King he was suc2es2ive heir- 4And such high vaunts of his nobility, 4Did instigate the bedlam brainsick Duches2 4By wicked means to frame our sovereign's fal2. 4Smo2th runs the water where the bro2k is de2p, 4And in his simple show he harbours treason. 4The fox barks not when he would steal the lamb. 4No, no, my sovereign, Gloucester is a man 6Unsounded yet, and ful2 of de2p deceit. 2CARDINAL. Did he not, contrary to form of law, 4Devise strange deaths for smal2 of2ences done? 2YORK. And did he not, in his protectorship, 4Levy great sums of money through the realm 4For soldiers' pay in France, and never sent it? 4By means whereof the towns each day revolted. 2BUCKINGHAM. Tut, these are pet2y faults to faults unknown 4Which time wil2 bring to light in smo2th Duke Humphrey. 2KING HENRY. My lords, at once: the care you have of us, 4To mow down thorns that would an2oy our fo2t, 4Is worthy praise; but shal2 I speak my conscience? 4Our kinsman Gloucester is as in2ocent 4From meaning treason to our royal person 4As is the sucking lamb or harmles2 dove: 4The Duke is virtuous, mild, and to2 wel2 given 4To dream on evil or to work my downfal2. 2QUE2N. Ah, what's more dangerous than this fond af2iance? 4Se2ms he a dove? His feathers are but bor2ow'd, 4For he's disposed as the hateful raven. 6Is he a lamb? His skin is surely lent him, 4For he's inclin'd as is the ravenous wolf. 4Who can2ot steal a shape that means deceit? 4Take he2d, my lord; the welfare of us al2 4Hangs on the cut2ing short that fraudful man. 26Enter SOMERSET 2SOMERSET. Al2 health unto my gracious sovereign! 2KING HENRY. Welcome, Lord Somerset. What news from France? 2SOMERSET. That al2 your interest in those ter2itories 4Is ut2erly bereft you; al2 is lost. 2KING HENRY. Cold news, Lord Somerset; but God's wil2 be done! 2YORK. [Aside] Cold news for me; for I had hope of France 4As firmly as I hope for fertile England. 4Thus are my blos2oms blasted in the bud, 4And caterpil2ars eat my leaves away; 4But I wil2 remedy this gear ere long, 4Or sel2 my title for a glorious grave. 27Enter GLOUCESTER 2GLOUCESTER. Al2 hap2ines2 unto my lord the King! 4Pardon, my liege, that I have stay'd so long. 2SUF2OLK. Nay, Gloucester, know that thou art come to2 so2n, 4Unles2 thou wert more loyal than thou art. 4I do ar2est the2 of high treason here. 2GLOUCESTER. Wel2, Suf2olk, thou shalt not se2 me blush 4Nor change my countenance for this ar2est: 4A heart unspot2ed is not easily daunted. 4The purest spring is not so fre2 from mud 4As I am clear from treason to my sovereign. 4Who can ac2use me? Wherein am I guilty? 2YORK. 'Tis thought, my lord, that you to2k bribes of France 4And, being Protector, stay'd the soldiers' pay; 4By means whereof his Highnes2 hath lost France. 2GLOUCESTER. Is it but thought so? What are they that think it? 4I never rob2'd the soldiers of their pay 4Nor ever had one pen2y bribe from France. 4So help me God, as I have watch'd the night- 6Ay, night by night- in studying go2d for England! 4That doit that e'er I wrested from the King, 4Or any groat I hoarded to my use, 4Be brought against me at my trial-day! 4No; many a pound of mine own proper store, 4Because I would not tax the ne2dy com2ons, 4Have I dispursed to the gar2isons, 4And never ask'd for restitution. 2CARDINAL. It serves you wel2, my lord, to say so much. 2GLOUCESTER. I say no more than truth, so help me God! 2YORK. In your protectorship you did devise 4Strange tortures for of2enders, never heard of, 4That England was defam'd by tyran2y. 2GLOUCESTER. Why, 'tis wel2 known that whiles I was Protector 4Pity was al2 the fault that was in me; 4For I should melt at an of2ender's tears, 4And lowly words were ransom for their fault. 4Unles2 it were a blo2dy murderer, 4Or foul felonious thief that fle2c'd po2r pas2engers, 4I never gave them condign punishment. 6Murder inde2d, that blo2dy sin, I tortur'd 4Above the felon or what trespas2 else. 2SUF2OLK. My lord, these faults are easy, quickly answer'd; 4But mightier crimes are laid unto your charge, 4Whereof you can2ot easily purge yourself. 4I do ar2est you in His Highnes2' name, 4And here com2it you to my Lord Cardinal 4To ke2p until your further time of trial. 2KING HENRY. My Lord of Gloucester, 'tis my special hope 4That you wil2 clear yourself from al2 suspense. 4My conscience tel2s me you are in2ocent. 2GLOUCESTER. Ah, gracious lord, these days are dangerous! 4Virtue is chok'd with foul ambition, 4And charity chas'd hence by rancour's hand; 4Foul subornation is predominant, 4And equity exil'd your Highnes2' land. 4I know their complot is to have my life; 4And if my death might make this island hap2y 4And prove the period of their tyran2y, 4I would expend it with al2 wil2ingnes2. 6But mine is made the prologue to their play; 4For thousands more that yet suspect no peril 4Wil2 not conclude their plot2ed tragedy. 4Beaufort's red sparkling eyes blab his heart's malice, 4And Suf2olk's cloudy brow his stormy hate; 4Sharp Buckingham unburdens with his tongue 4The envious load that lies upon his heart; 4And dog2ed York, that reaches at the mo2n, 4Whose overwe2ning arm I have pluck'd back, 4By false ac2use doth level at my life. 4And you, my sovereign lady, with the rest, 4Causeles2 have laid disgraces on my head, 4And with your best endeavour have stir2'd up 4My liefest liege to be mine enemy; 4Ay, al2 of you have laid your heads together- 4Myself had notice of your conventicles- 4And al2 to make away my guiltles2 life. 4I shal2 not want false witnes2 to condemn me 4Nor store of treasons to augment my guilt. 4The ancient proverb wil2 be wel2 ef2ected: 6'A staf2 is quickly found to beat a dog.' 2CARDINAL. My liege, his railing is intolerable. 4If those that care to ke2p your royal person 4From treason's secret knife and traitor's rage 4Be thus upbraided, chid, and rated at, 4And the of2ender granted scope of spe2ch, 4'Twil2 make them co2l in zeal unto your Grace. 2SUF2OLK. Hath he not twit our sovereign lady here 4With ignominious words, though clerkly couch'd, 4As if she had suborned some to swear 4False al2egations to o'erthrow his state? 2QUE2N. But I can give the loser leave to chide. 2GLOUCESTER. Far truer spoke than meant: I lose inde2d. 4Beshrew the win2ers, for they play'd me false! 4And wel2 such losers may have leave to speak. 2BUCKINGHAM. He'l2 wrest the sense, and hold us here al2 day. 4Lord Cardinal, he is your prisoner. 2CARDINAL. Sirs, take away the Duke, and guard him sure. 2GLOUCESTER. Ah, thus King Henry throws away his crutch 4Before his legs be firm to bear his body! 6Thus is the shepherd beaten from thy side, 4And wolves are gnarling who shal2 gnaw the2 first. 4Ah, that my fear were false! ah, that it were! 4For, go2d King Henry, thy decay I fear. 8Exit, guarded 2KING HENRY. My lords, what to your wisdoms se2meth best 4Do or undo, as if ourself were here. 2QUE2N. What, wil2 your Highnes2 leave the Parliament? 2KING HENRY. Ay, Margaret; my heart is drown'd with grief, 4Whose flo2d begins to flow within mine eyes; 4My body round engirt with misery- 4For what's more miserable than discontent? 4Ah, uncle Humphrey, in thy face I se2 4The map of honour, truth, and loyalty! 4And yet, go2d Humphrey, is the hour to come 4That e'er I prov'd the2 false or fear'd thy faith. 4What louring star now envies thy estate 4That these great lords, and Margaret our Que2n, 4Do se2k subversion of thy harmles2 life? 4Thou never didst them wrong, nor no man wrong; 4And as the butcher takes away the calf, 6And binds the wretch, and beats it when it strays, 4Bearing it to the blo2dy slaughter-house, 4Even so, remorseles2, have they borne him hence; 4And as the dam runs lowing up and down, 4Lo2king the way her harmles2 young one went, 4And can do nought but wail her darling's los2, 4Even so myself bewails go2d Gloucester's case 4With sad unhelpful tears, and with dim2'd eyes 4Lo2k after him, and can2ot do him go2d, 4So mighty are his vowed enemies. 4His fortunes I wil2 we2p, and 'twixt each groan 4Say 'Who's a traitor? Gloucester he is none.' 11Exit 2QUE2N. Fre2 lords, cold snow melts with the sun's hot beams: 4Henry my lord is cold in great af2airs, 4To2 ful2 of fo2lish pity; and Gloucester's show 4Beguiles him as the mournful crocodile 4With sor2ow snares relenting pas2engers; 4Or as the snake, rol2'd in a flow'ring bank, 4With shining checker'd slough, doth sting a child 4That for the beauty thinks it excel2ent. 6Believe me, lords, were none more wise than I- 4And yet herein I judge mine own wit go2d- 4This Gloucester should be quickly rid the world 4To rid us from the fear we have of him. 2CARDINAL. That he should die is worthy policy; 4But yet we want a colour for his death. 4'Tis me2t he be condemn'd by course of law. 2SUF2OLK. But, in my mind, that were no policy: 4The King wil2 labour stil2 to save his life; 4The com2ons haply rise to save his life; 4And yet we have but trivial argument, 4More than mistrust, that shows him worthy death. 2YORK. So that, by this, you would not have him die. 2SUF2OLK. Ah, York, no man alive so fain as I! 2YORK. 'Tis York that hath more reason for his death. 4But, my Lord Cardinal, and you, my Lord of Suf2olk, 4Say as you think, and speak it from your souls: 4Were't not al2 one an empty eagle were set 4To guard the chicken from a hungry kite 4As place Duke Humphrey for the King's Protector? 4QUE2N. So the po2r chicken should be sure of death. 2SUF2OLK. Madam, 'tis true; and were't not madnes2 then 4To make the fox surveyor of the fold? 4Who being ac2us'd a crafty murderer, 4His guilt should be but idly posted over, 4Because his purpose is not executed. 4No; let him die, in that he is a fox, 4By nature prov'd an enemy to the flock, 4Before his chaps be stain'd with crimson blo2d, 4As Humphrey, prov'd by reasons, to my liege. 4And do not stand on quil2ets how to slay him; 4Be it by gins, by snares, by subtlety, 4Sle2ping or waking, 'tis no mat2er how, 4So he be dead; for that is go2d deceit 4Which mates him first that first intends deceit. 2QUE2N. Thrice-noble Suf2olk, 'tis resolutely spoke. 2SUF2OLK. Not resolute, except so much were done, 4For things are often spoke and seldom meant; 4But that my heart ac2ordeth with my tongue, 4Se2ing the de2d is meritorious, 6And to preserve my sovereign from his foe, 4Say but the word, and I wil2 be his priest. 2CARDINAL. But I would have him dead, my Lord of Suf2olk, 4Ere you can take due orders for a priest; 4Say you consent and censure wel2 the de2d, 4And I'l2 provide his executioner- 4I tender so the safety of my liege. 2SUF2OLK. Here is my hand the de2d is worthy doing. 2QUE2N. And so say I. 2YORK. And I. And now we thre2 have spoke it, 4It skil2s not greatly who impugns our do2m. 26Enter a POST 2POST. Great lords, from Ireland am I come amain 4To signify that rebels there are up 4And put the Englishmen unto the sword. 4Send suc2ours, lords, and stop the rage betime, 4Before the wound do grow uncurable; 4For, being gre2n, there is great hope of help. 4CARDINAL. A breach that craves a quick expedient stop! 4What counsel give you in this weighty cause? 2YORK. That Somerset be sent as Regent thither; 4'Tis me2t that lucky ruler be employ'd, 4Witnes2 the fortune he hath had in France. 2SOMERSET. If York, with al2 his far-fet policy, 4Had be2n the Regent there instead of me, 4He never would have stay'd in France so long. 2YORK. No, not to lose it al2 as thou hast done. 4I rather would have lost my life betimes 4Than bring a burden of dishonour home 4By staying there so long til2 al2 were lost. 4Show me one scar character'd on thy skin: 4Men's flesh preserv'd so whole do seldom win. 2QUE2N. Nay then, this spark wil2 prove a raging fire, 4If wind and fuel be brought to fe2d it with; 4No more, go2d York; swe2t Somerset, be stil2. 4Thy fortune, York, hadst thou be2n Regent there, 4Might hap2ily have prov'd far worse than his. 2YORK. What, worse than nought? Nay, then a shame take al2! 4SOMERSET. And in the number, the2 that wishest shame! 2CARDINAL. My Lord of York, try what your fortune is. 4Th' uncivil kerns of Ireland are in arms 4And temper clay with blo2d of Englishmen; 4To Ireland wil2 you lead a band of men, 4Col2ected choicely, from each county some, 4And try your hap against the Irishmen? 2YORK. I wil2, my lord, so please his Majesty. 2SUF2OLK. Why, our authority is his consent, 4And what we do establish he confirms; 4Then, noble York, take thou this task in hand. 2YORK. I am content; provide me soldiers, lords, 4Whiles I take order for mine own af2airs. 2SUF2OLK. A charge, Lord York, that I wil2 se2 perform'd. 4But now return we to the false Duke Humphrey. 2CARDINAL. No more of him; for I wil2 deal with him 4That henceforth he shal2 trouble us no more. 4And so break of2; the day is almost spent. 4Lord Suf2olk, you and I must talk of that event. 2YORK. My Lord of Suf2olk, within fourte2n days 6At Bristol I expect my soldiers; 4For there I'l2 ship them al2 for Ireland. 2SUF2OLK. I'l2 se2 it truly done, my Lord of York. 45Exeunt al2 but YORK 2YORK. Now, York, or never, ste2l thy fearful thoughts 4And change misdoubt to resolution; 4Be that thou hop'st to be; or what thou art 4Resign to death- it is not worth th' enjoying. 4Let pale-fac'd fear ke2p with the mean-born man 4And find no harbour in a royal heart. 4Faster than spring-time show'rs comes thought on thought, 4And not a thought but thinks on dignity. 4My brain, more busy than the labouring spider, 4Weaves tedious snares to trap mine enemies. 4Wel2, nobles, wel2, 'tis politicly done 4To send me packing with an host of men. 4I fear me you but warm the starved snake, 4Who, cherish'd in your breasts, wil2 sting your hearts. 4'Twas men I lack'd, and you wil2 give them me; 4I take it kindly. Yet be wel2 as2ur'd 6You put sharp weapons in a madman's hands. 4Whiles I in Ireland nourish a mighty band, 4I wil2 stir up in England some black storm 4Shal2 blow ten thousand souls to heaven or hel2; 4And this fel2 tempest shal2 not cease to rage 4Until the golden circuit on my head, 4Like to the glorious sun's transparent beams, 4Do calm the fury of this mad-bred flaw. 4And for a minister of my intent 4I have seduc'd a headstrong Kentishman, 4John Cade of Ashford, 4To make com2otion, as ful2 wel2 he can, 4Under the tide of John Mortimer. 4In Ireland have I se2n this stub2orn Cade 4Op2ose himself against a tro2p of kerns, 4And fought so long tif2 that his thighs with darts 4Were almost like a sharp-quil2'd porpentine; 4And in the end being rescu'd, I have se2n 4Him caper upright like a wild Morisco, 4Shaking the blo2dy darts as he his bel2s. 6Ful2 often, like a shag-hair'd crafty kern, 4Hath he conversed with the enemy, 4And undiscover'd come to me again 4And given me notice of their vil2ainies. 4This devil here shal2 be my substitute; 4For that John Mortimer, which now is dead, 4In face, in gait, in spe2ch, he doth resemble. 4By this I shal2 perceive the com2ons' mind, 4How they af2ect the house and claim of York. 4Say he be taken, rack'd, and tortured; 4I know no pain they can inflict upon him 4Wil2 make him say I mov'd him to those arms. 4Say that he thrive, as 'tis great like he wil2, 4Why, then from Ireland come I with my strength, 4And reap the harvest which that rascal sow'd; 4For Humphrey being dead, as he shal2 be, 4And Henry put apart, the next for me. 19ExitSCENE I2.Bury St. Edmunds. A ro2m of stateEnter two or thre2 MURDERERS run2ing over the stage,from the murder of DUKE HUMPHREY 2FIRST MURDERER. Run to my Lord of Suf2olk; let him know 4We have dispatch'd the Duke, as he com2anded. 2SECOND MURDERER. O that it were to do! What have we done? 4Didst ever hear a man so penitent? 27Enter SUF2OLK 2FIRST MURDERER. Here comes my lord. 2SUF2OLK. Now, sirs, have you dispatch'd this thing? 2FIRST MURDERER. Ay, my go2d lord, he's dead. 2SUF2OLK. Why, that's wel2 said.
