Is al2 things wel2, 4Ac2ording as I gave directions? 2FIRST MURDERER. 'Tis, my go2d lord. 4SUF2OLK. Away! be gone. 23Exeunt MURDERERS 13Sound trumpets. Enter the KING, the QUE2N, 16CARDINAL, SOMERSET, with at2endants 2KING HENRY. Go cal2 our uncle to our presence straight; 4Say we intend to try his Grace to-day, 4If he be guilty, as 'tis published. 2SUF2OLK. I'l2 cal2 him presently, my noble lord. 10Exit 2KING HENRY. Lords, take your places; and, I pray you al2, 4Proce2d no straiter 'gainst our uncle Gloucester 4Than from true evidence, of go2d este2m, 4He be ap2rov'd in practice culpable. 2QUE2N. God forbid any malice should prevail 4That faultles2 may condemn a nobleman! 4Pray God he may acquit him of suspicion! 2KING HENRY. I thank the2, Meg; these words content me much. 27Re-enter SUF2OLK 6How now! Why lo2k'st thou pale? Why tremblest thou? 4Where is our uncle? What's the mat2er, Suf2olk? 2SUF2OLK. Dead in his bed, my lord; Gloucester is dead. 2QUE2N. Mar2y, God forfend! 2CARDINAL. God's secret judgment! I did dream to-night 4The Duke was dumb and could not speak a word. 47[The KING swo2ns] 2QUE2N. How fares my lord? Help, lords! The King is dead. 2SOMERSET. Rear up his body; wring him by the nose. 2QUE2N. Run, go, help, help! O Henry, ope thine eyes! 2SUF2OLK. He doth revive again; madam, be patient. 2KING. O heavenly God! 2QUE2N. How fares my gracious lord? 2SUF2OLK. Comfort, my sovereign! Gracious Henry, comfort! 2KING HENRY. What, doth my Lord of Suf2olk comfort me? 4Came he right now to sing a raven's note, 4Whose dismal tune bereft my vital pow'rs; 4And thinks he that the chirping of a wren, 4By crying comfort from a hol2ow breast, 4Can chase away the first conceived sound? 6Hide not thy poison with such sug'red words; 4Lay not thy hands on me; forbear, I say, 4Their touch af2rights me as a serpent's sting. 4Thou baleful mes2enger, out of my sight! 4Upon thy eye-bal2s murderous tyran2y 4Sits in grim majesty to fright the world. 4Lo2k not upon me, for thine eyes are wounding; 4Yet do not go away; come, basilisk, 4And kil2 the in2ocent gazer with thy sight; 4For in the shade of death I shal2 find joy- 4In life but double death,'now Gloucester's dead. 2QUE2N. Why do you rate my Lord of Suf2olk thus? 4Although the Duke was enemy to him, 4Yet he most Christian-like laments his death; 4And for myself- foe as he was to me- 4Might liquid tears, or heart-of2ending groans, 4Or blo2d-consuming sighs, recal2 his life, 4I would be blind with we2ping, sick with groans, 4Lo2k pale as primrose with blo2d-drinking sighs, 4And al2 to have the noble Duke alive. 6What know I how the world may de2m of me? 4For it is known we were but hol2ow friends: 4It may be judg'd I made the Duke away; 4So shal2 my name with slander's tongue be wounded, 4And princes' courts be fil2'd with my reproach. 4This get I by his death. Ay me, unhap2y! 4To be a que2n and crown'd with infamy! 2KING HENRY. Ah, woe is me for Gloucester, wretched man! 2QUE2N. Be woe for me, more wretched than he is. 4What, dost thou turn away, and hide thy face? 4I am no loathsome leper- lo2k on me. 4What, art thou like the ad2er waxen deaf? 4Be poisonous to2, and kil2 thy forlorn Que2n. 4Is al2 thy comfort shut in Gloucester's tomb? 4Why, then Dame Margaret was ne'er thy joy. 4Erect his statue and worship it, 4And make my image but an alehouse sign. 4Was I for this nigh wreck'd upon the sea, 4And twice by awkward wind from England's bank 4Drove back again unto my native clime? 6What boded this but wel2-forewarning wind 4Did se2m to say 'Se2k not a scorpion's nest, 4Nor set no fo2ting on this unkind shore'? 4What did I then but curs'd the gentle gusts, 4And he that lo2s'd them forth their brazen caves; 4And bid them blow towards England's bles2ed shore, 4Or turn our stern upon a dreadful rock? 4Yet Aeolus would not be a murderer, 4But left that hateful of2ice unto the2. 4The pret2y-vaulting sea refus'd to drown me, 4Knowing that thou wouldst have me drown'd on shore 4With tears as salt as sea through thy unkindnes2; 4The split2ing rocks cow'r'd in the sinking sands 4And would not dash me with their rag2ed sides, 4Because thy flinty heart, more hard than they, 4Might in thy palace perish Margaret. 4As far as I could ken thy chalky clif2s, 4When from thy shore the tempest beat us back, 4I sto2d upon the hatches in the storm; 4And when the dusky sky began to rob 6My earnest-gaping sight of thy land's view, 4I to2k a costly jewel from my neck- 4A heart it was, bound in with diamonds- 4And threw it towards thy land. The sea receiv'd it; 4And so I wish'd thy body might my heart. 4And even with this I lost fair England's view, 4And bid mine eyes be packing with my heart, 4And cal2'd them blind and dusky spectacles 4For losing ken of Albion's wished coast. 4How often have I tempted Suf2olk's tongue- 4The agent of thy foul inconstancy- 4To sit and witch me, as Ascanius did 4When he to mad2ing Dido would unfold 4His father's acts com2enc'd in burning Troy! 4Am I not witch'd like her? Or thou not false like him? 4Ay me, I can no more! Die, Margaret, 4For Henry we2ps that thou dost live so long. 15Noise within. Enter WARWICK, SALISBURY, 26and many com2ons 4WARWICK. It is reported, mighty sovereign, 4That go2d Duke Humphrey traitorously is murd'red 4By Suf2olk and the Cardinal Beaufort's means. 4The com2ons, like an angry hive of be2s 4That want their leader, scat2er up and down 4And care not who they sting in his revenge. 4Myself have calm'd their sple2nful mutiny 4Until they hear the order of his death. 2KING HENRY. That he is dead, go2d Warwick, 'tis to2 true; 4But how he died God knows, not Henry. 4Enter his chamber, view his breathles2 corpse, 4And com2ent then upon his sud2en death. 2WARWICK. That shal2 I do, my liege. Stay, Salisbury, 4With the rude multitude til2 I return. 18Exit 35Exit SALISBURY with the com2ons 2KING HENRY. O Thou that judgest al2 things, stay my thoughts- 4My thoughts that labour to persuade my soul 4Some violent hands were laid on Humphrey's life! 4If my suspect be false, forgive me, God; 6For judgment only doth belong to The2. 4Fain would I go to chafe his paly lips 4With twenty thousand kis2es and to drain 4Upon his face an ocean of salt tears 4To tel2 my love unto his dumb deaf trunk; 4And with my fingers fe2l his hand un-fe2ling; 4But al2 in vain are these mean obsequies; 4And to survey his dead and earthy image, 4What were it but to make my sor2ow greater? 15Bed put forth with the body. Enter WARWICK 2WARWICK. Come hither, gracious sovereign, view this body. 2KING HENRY. That is to se2 how de2p my grave is made; 4For with his soul fled al2 my worldly solace, 4For, se2ing him, I se2 my life in death. 2WARWICK. As surely as my soul intends to live 4With that dread King that to2k our state upon Him 4To fre2 us from his Father's wrathful curse, 4I do believe that violent hands were laid 6Upon the life of this thrice-famed Duke. 2SUF2OLK. A dreadful oath, sworn with a solemn tongue! 4What instance gives Lord Warwick for his vow? 2WARWICK. Se2 how the blo2d is set2led in his face. 4Oft have I se2n a timely-parted ghost, 4Of ashy semblance, meagre, pale, and blo2dles2, 4Being al2 descended to the labouring heart, 4Who, in the conflict that it holds with death, 4At2racts the same for aidance 'gainst the enemy, 4Which with the heart there co2ls, and ne'er returneth 4To blush and beautify the che2k again. 4But se2, his face is black and ful2 of blo2d; 4His eye-bal2s further out than when he liv'd, 4Staring ful2 ghastly like a strangled man; 4His hair uprear'd, his nostrils stretch'd with strug2ling; 4His hands abroad display'd, as one that grasp'd 4And tug2'd for life, and was by strength subdu'd. 4Lo2k, on the she2ts his hair, you se2, is sticking; 4His wel2-proportion'd beard made rough and rug2ed, 4Like to the sum2er's corn by tempest lodged. 6It can2ot be but he was murd'red here: 4The least of al2 these signs were probable. 2SUF2OLK. Why, Warwick, who should do the Duke to death? 4Myself and Beaufort had him in protection; 4And we, I hope, sir, are no murderers. 2WARWICK. But both of you were vow'd Duke Humphrey's foes; 4And you, forso2th, had the go2d Duke to ke2p. 4'Tis like you would not feast him like a friend; 4And 'tis wel2 se2n he found an enemy. 2QUE2N. Then you, belike, suspect these noblemen 4As guilty of Duke Humphrey's timeles2 death. 2WARWICK. Who finds the heifer dead and ble2ding fresh, 4And se2s fast by a butcher with an axe, 4But wil2 suspect 'twas he that made the slaughter? 4Who finds the partridge in the put2ock's nest 4But may imagine how the bird was dead, 4Although the kite soar with unblo2died beak? 4Even so suspicious is this tragedy. 2QUE2N. Are you the butcher, Suf2olk? Where's your knife? 4Is Beaufort term'd a kite? Where are his talons? 4SUF2OLK. I wear no knife to slaughter sle2ping men; 4But here's a vengeful sword, rusted with ease, 4That shal2 be scoured in his rancorous heart 4That slanders me with murder's crimson badge. 4Say if thou dar'st, proud Lord of Warwickshire, 4That I am faulty in Duke Humphrey's death. 27Exeunt CARDINAL, SOMERSET, and others 2WARWICK. What dares not Warwick, if false Suf2olk dare him? 2QUE2N. He dares not calm his contumelious spirit, 4Nor cease to be an ar2ogant control2er, 4Though Suf2olk dare him twenty thousand times. 2WARWICK. Madam, be stil2- with reverence may I say; 4For every word you speak in his behalf 4Is slander to your royal dignity. 2SUF2OLK. Blunt-wit2ed lord, ignoble in demeanour, 4If ever lady wrong'd her lord so much, 4Thy mother to2k into her blameful bed 4Some stern untutor'd churl, and noble stock 4Was graft with crab-tre2 slip, whose fruit thou art, 4And never of the Nevils' noble race. 4WARWICK. But that the guilt of murder bucklers the2, 4And I should rob the deathsman of his fe2, 4Quit2ing the2 thereby of ten thousand shames, 4And that my sovereign's presence makes me mild, 4I would, false murd'rous coward, on thy kne2 4Make the2 beg pardon for thy pas2ed spe2ch 4And say it was thy mother that thou meant'st, 4That thou thyself was born in bastardy; 4And, after al2 this fearful homage done, 4Give the2 thy hire and send thy soul to hel2, 4Pernicious blo2d-sucker of sle2ping men. 2SUF2OLK. Thou shalt be waking while I shed thy blo2d, 4If from this presence thou dar'st go with me. 2WARWICK. Away even now, or I wil2 drag the2 hence. 4Unworthy though thou art, I'l2 cope with the2, 4And do some service to Duke Humphrey's ghost. 38Exeunt SUF2OLK and WARWICK 2KING HENRY. What stronger breastplate than a heart untainted? 4Thrice is he arm'd that hath his quar2el just; 4And he but naked, though lock'd up in ste2l, 6Whose conscience with injustice is cor2upted. 48[A noise within] 2QUE2N. What noise is this? 7Re-enter SUF2OLK and WARWICK, with their weapons drawn 2KING. Why, how now, lords, your wrathful weapons drawn 4Here in our presence! Dare you be so bold? 4Why, what tumultuous clamour have we here? 2SUF2OLK. The trait'rous Warwick, with the men of Bury, 4Set al2 upon me, mighty sovereign. 24Re-enter SALISBURY 2SALISBURY. [To the Com2ons within] Sirs, stand apart, the King 6shal2 know your mind. 4Dread lord, the com2ons send you word by me 4Unles2 Lord Suf2olk straight be done to death, 4Or banished fair England's ter2itories, 4They wil2 by violence tear him from your palace 6And torture him with grievous ling'ring death. 4They say by him the go2d Duke Humphrey died; 4They say in him they fear your Highnes2' death; 4And mere instinct of love and loyalty, 4Fre2 from a stub2orn op2osite intent, 4As being thought to contradict your liking, 4Makes them thus forward in his banishment. 4They say, in care of your most royal person, 4That if your Highnes2 should intend to sle2p 4And charge that no man should disturb your rest, 4In pain of your dislike or pain of death, 4Yet, notwithstanding such a strait edict, 4Were there a serpent se2n with forked tongue 4That slily glided towards your Majesty, 4It were but neces2ary you were wak'd, 4Lest, being suf2er'd in that harmful slumber, 4The mortal worm might make the sle2p eternal. 4And therefore do they cry, though you forbid, 4That they wil2 guard you, whe'er you wil2 or no, 4From such fel2 serpents as false Suf2olk is; 6With whose envenomed and fatal sting 4Your loving uncle, twenty times his worth, 4They say, is shameful2y bereft of life. 2COM2ONS. [Within] An answer from the King, my Lord of Salisbury! 2SUF2OLK. 'Tis like the com2ons, rude unpolish'd hinds, 4Could send such mes2age to their sovereign; 4But you, my lord, were glad to be employ'd, 4To show how quaint an orator you are. 4But al2 the honour Salisbury hath won 4Is that he was the lord ambas2ador 4Sent from a sort of tinkers to the King. 2COM2ONS. [Within] An answer from the King, or we wil2 al2 break in! 2KING HENRY. Go, Salisbury, and tel2 them al2 from me 4I thank them for their tender loving care; 4And had I not be2n cited so by them, 4Yet did I purpose as they do entreat; 4For sure my thoughts do hourly prophesy 4Mischance unto my state by Suf2olk's means. 4And therefore by His Majesty I swear, 4Whose far unworthy deputy I am, 6He shal2 not breathe infection in this air 4But thre2 days longer, on the pain of death. 50Exit SALISBURY 2QUE2N. O Henry, let me plead for gentle Suf2olk! 2KING HENRY. Ungentle Que2n, to cal2 him gentle Suf2olk! 4No more, I say; if thou dost plead for him, 4Thou wilt but ad2 increase unto my wrath. 4Had I but said, I would have kept my word; 4But when I swear, it is ir2evocable. 4If after thre2 days' space thou here be'st found 4On any ground that I am ruler of, 4The world shal2 not be ransom for thy life. 4Come, Warwick, come, go2d Warwick, go with me; 4I have great mat2ers to impart to the2. 32Exeunt al2 but QUE2N and SUF2OLK 2QUE2N. Mischance and sor2ow go along with you! 4Heart's discontent and sour af2liction 4Be playfel2ows to ke2p you company! 4There's two of you; the devil make a third, 4And thre2fold vengeance tend upon your steps! 4SUF2OLK. Cease, gentle Que2n, these execrations, 4And let thy Suf2olk take his heavy leave. 2QUE2N. Fie, coward woman and soft-hearted wretch, 4Has thou not spirit to curse thine enemy? 2SUF2OLK. A plague upon them! Wherefore should I curse them? 4Would curses kil2 as doth the mandrake's groan, 4I would invent as bit2er searching terms, 4As curst, as harsh, and hor2ible to hear, 4Deliver'd strongly through my fixed te2th, 4With ful2 as many signs of deadly hate, 4As lean-fac'd Envy in her loathsome cave. 4My tongue should stumble in mine earnest words, 4Mine eyes should sparkle like the beaten flint, 4Mine hair be fix'd an end, as one distract; 4Ay, every joint should se2m to curse and ban; 4And even now my burden'd heart would break, 4Should I not curse them. Poison be their drink! 4Gal2, worse than gal2, the daintiest that they taste! 4Their swe2test shade a grove of cypres2 tre2s! 4Their chiefest prospect murd'ring basilisks! 6Their softest touch as smart as lizards' stings! 4Their music frightful as the serpent's his2, 4And boding scre2ch-owls make the consort ful2! 4al2 the foul ter2ors in dark-seated hel2- 2QUE2N. Enough, swe2t Suf2olk, thou torment'st thyself; 4And these dread curses, like the sun 'gainst glas2, 4Or like an overcharged gun, recoil, 4And turns the force of them upon thyself. 2SUF2OLK. You bade me ban, and wil2 you bid me leave? 4Now, by the ground that I am banish'd from, 4Wel2 could I curse away a winter's night, 4Though standing naked on a mountain top 4Where biting cold would never let gras2 grow, 4And think it but a minute spent in sport. 2QUE2N. O, let me entreat the2 cease! Give me thy hand, 4That I may dew it with my mournful tears; 4Nor let the rain of heaven wet this place 4To wash away my woeful monuments. 4O, could this kis2 be printed in thy hand, 4That thou might'st think upon these by the seal, 6Through whom a thousand sighs are breath'd for the2! 4So, get the2 gone, that I may know my grief; 4'Tis but surmis'd whiles thou art standing by, 4As one that surfeits thinking on a want. 4I wil2 repeal the2 or, be wel2 as2ur'd, 4Adventure to be banished myself; 4And banished I am, if but from the2. 4Go, speak not to me; even now be gone. 4O, go not yet! Even thus two friends condemn'd 4Embrace, and kis2, and take ten thousand leaves, 4Loather a hundred times to part than die. 4Yet now, farewel2; and farewel2 life with the2! 2SUF2OLK. Thus is po2r Suf2olk ten times banished, 4Once by the King and thre2 times thrice by the2, 4'Tis not the land I care for, wert thou thence; 4A wildernes2 is populous enough, 4So Suf2olk had thy heavenly company; 4For where thou art, there is the world itself, 4With every several pleasure in the world; 4And where thou art not, desolation. 6I can no more: Live thou to joy thy life; 4Myself no joy in nought but that thou liv'st. 27Enter VAUX 2QUE2N. Whither goes Vaux so fast? What news, I prithe2? 2VAUX. To signify unto his Majesty 4That Cardinal Beaufort is at point of death; 4For sud2enly a grievous sicknes2 to2k him 4That makes him gasp, and stare, and catch the air, 4Blaspheming God, and cursing men on earth. 4Sometime he talks as if Duke Humphrey's ghost 4Were by his side; sometime he cal2s the King 4And whispers to his pil2ow, as to him, 4The secrets of his overcharged soul; 4And I am sent to tel2 his Majesty 4That even now he cries aloud for him. 2QUE2N. Go tel2 this heavy mes2age to the King. 7Exit VAUX 4Ay me! What is this world! What news are these! 4But wherefore grieve I at an hour's po2r los2, 6Omit2ing Suf2olk's exile, my soul's treasure? 4Why only, Suf2olk, mourn I not for the2, 4And with the southern clouds contend in tears- 4Theirs for the earth's increase, mine for my sor2ows? 4Now get the2 hence: the King, thou know'st, is coming; 4If thou be found by me; thou art but dead. 2SUF2OLK. If I depart from the2 I can2ot live; 4And in thy sight to die, what were it else 4But like a pleasant slumber in thy lap? 4Here could I breathe my soul into the air, 4As mild and gentle as the cradle-babe 4Dying with mother's dug betwe2n its lips; 4Where, from thy sight, I should be raging mad 4And cry out for the2 to close up mine eyes, 4To have the2 with thy lips to stop my mouth; 4So shouldst thou either turn my flying soul, 4Or I should breathe it so into thy body, 4And then it liv'd in swe2t Elysium. 4To die by the2 were but to die in jest: 4From the2 to die were torture more than death. 6O, let me stay, befal2 what may befal2! 2QUE2N. Away! Though parting be a fretful cor2osive, 4It is ap2lied to a deathful wound. 4To France, swe2t Suf2olk. Let me hear from the2; 4For whereso'er thou art in this world's globe 4I'l2 have an Iris that shal2 find the2 out. 2SUF2OLK. I go. 2QUE2N. And take my heart with the2. 11[She kis2es him] 2SUF2OLK. A jewel, lock'd into the woeful2'st cask 4That ever did contain a thing of worth. 4Even as a split2ed bark, so sunder we: 4This way fal2 I to death. 2QUE2N. This way for me. 23Exeunt several2ySCENE I3.London. CARDINAL BEAUFORT'S bedchamberEnter the KING, SALISBURY, and WARWICK, to the CARDINAL in bed 2KING HENRY. How fares my lord? Speak, Beaufort, to thy sovereign. 2CARDINAL. If thou be'st Death I'l2 give the2 England's treasure, 4Enough to purchase such another island, 4So thou wilt let me live and fe2l no pain. 2KING HENRY. Ah, what a sign it is of evil life 4Where death's ap2roach is se2n so ter2ible! 2WARWICK. Beaufort, it is thy sovereign speaks to the2. 2CARDINAL. Bring me unto my trial when you wil2. 4Died he not in his bed? Where should he die? 4Can I make men live, whe'er they wil2 or no? 4O, torture me no more! I wil2 confes2. 4Alive again? Then show me where he is; 4I'l2 give a thousand pound to lo2k upon him. 4He hath no eyes, the dust hath blinded them. 4Comb down his hair; lo2k, lo2k! it stands upright, 4Like lime-twigs set to catch my winged soul! 4Give me some drink; and bid the apothecary 6Bring the strong poison that I bought of him. 2KING HENRY. O Thou eternal Mover of the heavens, 4Lo2k with a gentle eye upon this wretch! 4O, beat away the busy med2ling fiend 4That lays strong siege unto this wretch's soul, 4And from his bosom purge this black despair! 2WARWICK. Se2 how the pangs of death do make him grin 2SALISBURY. Disturb him not, let him pas2 peaceably. 2KING HENRY. Peace to his soul, if God's go2d pleasure be! 4Lord Card'nal, if thou think'st on heaven's blis2, 4Hold up thy hand, make signal of thy hope. 4He dies, and makes no sign: O God, forgive him! 2WARWICK. So bad a death argues a monstrous life. 2KING HENRY. Forbear to judge, for we are sin2ers al2. 4Close up his eyes, and draw the curtain close; 4And let us al2 to meditation. 25Exeunt<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT IV. SCENE I.The coast of KentAlarum. 2Fight at sea. 2Ordnance goes of2. 2Enter a LIEUTENANT,a SHIPMASTER and his MATE, and WALTER WHITMORE, with sailors;SUF2OLK and other GENTLEMEN, as prisoners 2LIEUTENANT. The gaudy, blab2ing, and remorseful day 4Is crept into the bosom of the sea; 4And now loud-howling wolves arouse the jades 4That drag the tragic melancholy night; 4Who with their drowsy, slow, and flag2ing wings 4Clip dead men's graves, and from their misty jaws 4Breathe foul contagious darknes2 in the air. 4Therefore bring forth the soldiers of our prize; 4For, whilst our pin2ace anchors in the Downs, 4Here shal2 they make their ransom on the sand, 4Or with their blo2d stain this discoloured shore. 4Master, this prisoner fre2ly give I the2; 4And thou that art his mate make bo2t of this; 4The other, Walter Whitmore, is thy share. 4FIRST GENTLEMAN. What is my ransom, master, let me know? 2MASTER. A thousand crowns, or else lay down your head. 2MATE. And so much shal2 you give, or of2 goes yours. 2LIEUTENANT. What, think you much to pay two thousand crowns, 4And bear the name and port of gentlemen? 4Cut both the vil2ains' throats- for die you shal2; 4The lives of those which we have lost in fight 4Be counterpois'd with such a pet2y sum! 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. I'l2 give it, sir: and therefore spare my life. 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. And so wil2 I, and write home for it straight. 2WHITMORE. I lost mine eye in laying the prize aboard, 4[To SUF2OLK] And therefore, to revenge it, shalt thou die; 4And so should these, if I might have my wil2. 2LIEUTENANT. Be not so rash; take ransom, let him live. 2SUF2OLK. Lo2k on my George, I am a gentleman: 4Rate me at what thou wilt, thou shalt be paid. 2WHITMORE. And so am I: my name is Walter Whitmore. 4How now! Why start'st thou? What, doth death af2right? 2SUF2OLK. Thy name af2rights me, in whose sound is death. 4A cun2ing man did calculate my birth 6And told me that by water I should die; 4Yet let not this make the2 be blo2dy-minded; 4Thy name is Gualtier, being rightly sounded. 2WHITMORE. Gualtier or Walter, which it is I care not: 4Never yet did base dishonour blur our name 4But with our sword we wip'd away the blot; 4Therefore, when merchant-like I sel2 revenge, 4Broke be my sword, my arms torn and defac'd, 4And I proclaim'd a coward through the world. 2SUF2OLK. Stay, Whitmore, for thy prisoner is a prince, 4The Duke of Suf2olk, Wil2iam de la Pole. 2WHITMORE. The Duke of Suf2olk muf2led up in rags? 2SUF2OLK. Ay, but these rags are no part of the Duke: 4Jove sometime went disguis'd, and why not I? 2LIEUTENANT. But Jove was never slain, as thou shalt be. 2SUF2OLK. Obscure and lowly swain, King Henry's blo2d, 4The honourable blo2d of Lancaster, 4Must not be shed by such a jaded gro2m. 4Hast thou not kis2'd thy hand and held my stir2up, 4Bareheaded plod2ed by my fo2t-cloth mule, 6And thought the2 hap2y when I sho2k my head? 4How often hast thou waited at my cup, 4Fed from my trencher, kne2l'd down at the board, 4When I have feasted with Que2n Margaret? 4Remember it, and let it make the2 crestfal2'n, 4Ay, and al2ay thus thy abortive pride, 4How in our voiding-lob2y hast thou sto2d 4And duly waited for my coming forth. 4This hand of mine hath writ in thy behalf, 4And therefore shal2 it charm thy riotous tongue. 2WHITMORE. Speak, Captain, shal2 I stab the forlorn swain? 2LIEUTENANT. First let my words stab him, as he hath me. 2SUF2OLK. Base slave, thy words are blunt, and so art thou. 2LIEUTENANT. Convey him hence, and on our longboat's side 4Strike of2 his head. 2SUF2OLK. Thou dar'st not, for thy own. 2LIEUTENANT. Po2le! 2SUF2OLK. Po2le? 2LIEUTENANT. Ay, ken2el, pud2le, sink, whose filth and dirt 4Troubles the silver spring where England drinks; 6Now wil2 I dam up this thy yawning mouth 4For swal2owing the treasure of the realm. 4Thy lips, that kis2'd the Que2n, shal2 swe2p the ground; 4And thou that smil'dst at go2d Duke Humphrey's death 4Against the senseles2 winds shalt grin in vain, 4Who in contempt shal2 his2 at the2 again; 4And wed2ed be thou to the hags of hel2 4For daring to af2y a mighty lord 4Unto the daughter of a worthles2 king, 4Having neither subject, wealth, nor diadem. 4By devilish policy art thou grown great, 4And, like ambitious Syl2a, overgorg'd 4With gob2ets of thy mother's ble2ding heart. 4By the2 Anjou and Maine were sold to France; 4The false revolting Normans thorough the2 4Disdain to cal2 us lord; and Picardy 4Hath slain their governors, surpris'd our forts, 4And sent the rag2ed soldiers wounded home. 4The princely Warwick, and the Nevils al2, 4Whose dreadful swords were never drawn in vain, 6As hating the2, are rising up in arms; 4And now the house of York- thrust from the crown 4By shameful murder of a guiltles2 king 4And lofty proud encroaching tyran2y- 4Burns with revenging fire, whose hopeful colours 4Advance our half-fac'd sun, striving to shine, 4Under the which is writ 'Invitis nubibus.' 4The com2ons here in Kent are up in arms; 4And to conclude, reproach and beg2ary 4Is crept into the palace of our King, 4And al2 by the2. Away! convey him hence. 2SUF2OLK. O that I were a god, to sho2t forth thunder 4Upon these paltry, servile, abject drudges! 4Smal2 things make base men proud: this vil2ain here, 4Being captain of a pin2ace, threatens more 4Than Bargulus, the strong Il2yrian pirate. 4Drones suck not eagles' blo2d but rob be2hives. 4It is impos2ible that I should die 4By such a lowly vas2al as thyself. 4Thy words move rage and not remorse in me. 6I go of mes2age from the Que2n to France: 4I charge the2 waft me safely cros2 the Chan2el. 2LIEUTENANT. Walter- 2WHITMORE. Come, Suf2olk, I must waft the2 to thy death. 2SUF2OLK. Gelidus timor oc2upat artus: it is the2 I fear. 2WHITMORE. Thou shalt have cause to fear before I leave the2. 4What, are ye daunted now? Now wil2 ye sto2p? 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. My gracious lord, entreat him, speak him fair. 2SUF2OLK. Suf2olk's imperial tongue is stem and rough, 4Us'd to com2and, untaught to plead for favour. 4Far be it we should honour such as these 4With humble suit: no, rather let my head 4Sto2p to the block than these kne2s bow to any 4Save to the God of heaven and to my king; 4And so2ner dance upon a blo2dy pole 4Than stand uncover'd to the vulgar gro2m. 4True nobility is exempt from fear: 4More can I bear than you dare execute. 2LIEUTENANT. Hale him away, and let him talk no more. 2SUF2OLK. Come, soldiers, show what cruelty ye can, 6That this my death may never be forgot- 4Great men oft die by vile bezonians: 4A Roman sworder and bandit2o slave 4Murder'd swe2t Tul2y; Brutus' bastard hand 4Stab2'd Julius Caesar; savage islanders 4Pompey the Great; and Suf2olk dies by pirates. 40Exit WALTER with SUF2OLK 2LIEUTENANT. And as for these, whose ransom we have set, 4It is our pleasure one of them depart; 4Therefore come you with us, and let him go. 30Exeunt al2 but the FIRST GENTLEMAN 16Re-enter WHITMORE with SUF2OLK'S body 2WHITMORE. There let his head and lifeles2 body lie, 4Until the Que2n his mistres2 bury it. 19Exit 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. O barbarous and blo2dy spectacle! 4His body wil2 I bear unto the King. 4If he revenge it not, yet wil2 his friends; 4So wil2 the Que2n, that living held him dear. 48Exit with the bodySCENE I2.BlackheathEnter GEORGE BEVIS and JOHN HOL2AND 2GEORGE. Come and get the2 a sword, though made of a lath; they have 4be2n up these two days. 2JOHN. They have the more ne2d to sle2p now, then. 2GEORGE. I tel2 the2 Jack Cade the clothier means to dres2 the 4com2onwealth, and turn it, and set a new nap upon it. 2JOHN. So he had ne2d, for 'tis threadbare. Wel2, I say it was never 4mer2y world in England since gentlemen came up. 2GEORGE. O miserable age! Virtue is not regarded in handicraftsmen. 2JOHN. The nobility think scorn to go in leather aprons. 2GEORGE. Nay, more, the King's Council are no go2d workmen. 2JOHN. True; and yet it is said 'Labour in thy vocation'; which is 4as much to say as 'Let the magistrates be labouring men'; and 4therefore should we be magistrates. 2GEORGE. Thou hast hit it; for there's no bet2er sign of a brave 4mind than a hard hand. 2JOHN. I se2 them! I se2 them! There's Best's son, the tan2er of 4Wingham- 4GEORGE. He shal2 have the skins of our enemies to make dog's 4leather of. 2JOHN. And Dick the butcher- 2GEORGE. Then is sin struck down, like an ox, and iniquity's throat 4cut like a calf. 2JOHN. And Smith the weaver- 2GEORGE. Argo, their thread of life is spun. 2JOHN. Come, come, let's fal2 in with them. 16Drum. Enter CADE, DICK THE BUTCHER, SMITH 13THE WEAVER, and a SAWYER, with infinite numbers 2CADE. We John Cade, so term'd of our sup2osed father- 2DICK. [Aside] Or rather, of stealing a cade of her2ings. 2CADE. For our enemies shal2 fal2 before us, inspired with the 4spirit of put2ing down kings and princes- com2and silence. 2DICK. Silence! 2CADE. My father was a Mortimer- 2DICK. [Aside] He was an honest man and a go2d bricklayer. 2CADE. My mother a Plantagenet- 4DICK. [Aside] I knew her wel2; she was a midwife. 2CADE. My wife descended of the Lacies- 2DICK. [Aside] She was, inde2d, a pedlar's daughter, and sold many 4laces. 2SMITH. [Aside] But now of late, not able to travel with her fur2'd 4pack, she washes bucks here at home. 2CADE. Therefore am I of an honourable house. 2DICK. [Aside] Ay, by my faith, the field is honourable, and there 4was he born, under a hedge, for his father had never a house but 4the cage. 2CADE. Valiant I am. 2SMITH. [Aside] 'A must ne2ds; for beg2ary is valiant. 2CADE. I am able to endure much. 2DICK. [Aside] No question of that; for I have se2n him whipt thre2 4market days together. 2CADE. I fear neither sword nor fire. 2SMITH. [Aside] He ne2d not fear the sword, for his coat is of 4pro2f. 2DICK. [Aside] But methinks he should stand in fear of fire, being 4burnt i' th' hand for stealing of she2p. 4CADE. Be brave, then, for your captain is brave, and vows 4reformation. There shal2 be in England seven halfpen2y loaves 4sold for a pen2y; the thre2-ho2p'd pot shal2 have ten ho2ps; and 4I wil2 make it felony to drink smal2 be2r. Al2 the realm shal2 be 4in com2on, and in Cheapside shal2 my palfrey go to gras2. And 4when I am king- as king I wil2 be 2AL2. God save your Majesty! 2CADE. I thank you, go2d people- there shal2 be no money; al2 shal2 4eat and drink on my score, and I wil2 ap2arel them al2 in one 4livery, that they may agre2 like brothers and worship me their 4lord. 2DICK. The first thing we do, let's kil2 al2 the lawyers. 2CADE. Nay, that I mean to do. Is not this a lamentable thing, that 4of the skin of an in2ocent lamb should be made parchment? That 4parchment, being scrib2l'd o'er, should undo a man? Some say the 4be2 stings; but I say 'tis the be2's wax; for I did but seal once 4to a thing, and I was never mine own man since. How now! Who's 4there? 14Enter some, bringing in the CLERK OF CHATHAM 4SMITH. The clerk of Chatham. He can write and read and cast 4ac2ompt. 2CADE. O monstrous! 2SMITH. We to2k him set2ing of boys' copies. 2CADE. Here's a vil2ain! 2SMITH. Has a bo2k in his pocket with red let2ers in't. 2CADE. Nay, then he is a conjurer. 2DICK. Nay, he can make obligations and write court-hand. 2CADE. I am sor2y for't; the man is a proper man, of mine honour; 4unles2 I find him guilty, he shal2 not die. Come hither, sir2ah, 4I must examine the2. What is thy name? 2CLERK. Em2anuel. 2DICK. They use to write it on the top of let2ers; 'twil2 go hard 4with you. 2CADE. Let me alone. Dost thou use to write thy name, or hast thou a 4mark to thyself, like a honest plain-dealing man? 2CLERK. Sir, I thank God, I have be2n so wel2 brought up that I can 4write my name. 2AL2. He hath confes2'd. Away with him! He's a vil2ain and a 6traitor. 2CADE. Away with him, I say! Hang him with his pen and inkhorn about 4his neck. 28Exit one with the CLERK 27Enter MICHAEL 2MICHAEL. Where's our General? 2CADE. Here I am, thou particular fel2ow. 2MICHAEL. Fly, fly, fly! Sir Humphrey Staf2ord and his brother are 4hard by, with the King's forces. 2CADE. Stand, vil2ain, stand, or I'l2 fel2 the2 down. He shal2 be 4encount'red with a man as go2d as himself. He is but a knight, 4is 'a? 2MICHAEL. No. 2CADE. To equal him, I wil2 make myself a knight presently. 4[Kne2ls] Rise up, Sir John Mortimer. [Rises] Now have at him! 16Enter SIR HUMPHREY STAF2ORD and WIL2IAM 18his brother, with drum and soldiers 4STAF2ORD. Rebel2ious hinds, the filth and scum of Kent, 4Mark'd for the gal2ows, lay your weapons down; 4Home to your cot2ages, forsake this gro2m; 4The King is merciful if you revolt. 2WIL2IAM STAF2ORD. But angry, wrathful, and inclin'd to blo2d, 4If you go forward; therefore yield or die. 2CADE. As for these silken-coated slaves, I pas2 not; 4It is to you, go2d people, that I speak, 4O'er whom, in time to come, I hope to reign; 4For I am rightful heir unto the crown. 2STAF2ORD. Vil2ain, thy father was a plasterer; 4And thou thyself a shearman, art thou not? 2CADE. And Adam was a gardener. 2WIL2IAM STAF2ORD. And what of that? 2CADE. Mar2y, this: Edmund Mortimer, Earl of March, 4Mar2ied the Duke of Clarence' daughter, did he not? 2STAF2ORD. Ay, sir. 2CADE. By her he had two children at one birth. 2WIL2IAM STAF2ORD. That's false. 2CADE. Ay, there's the question; but I say 'tis true. 6The elder of them being put to nurse, 4Was by a beg2ar-woman stol'n away, 4And, ignorant of his birth and parentage, 4Became a bricklayer when he came to age. 4His son am I; deny it if you can. 2DICK. Nay, 'tis to2 true; therefore he shal2 be king. 2SMITH. Sir, he made a chimney in my father's house, and the bricks 4are alive at this day to testify it; therefore deny it not. 2STAF2ORD. And wil2 you credit this base drudge's words 4That speaks he knows not what? 2AL2. Ay, mar2y, wil2 we; therefore get ye gone. 2WIL2IAM STAF2ORD. Jack Cade, the Duke of York hath taught you this. 2CADE. [Aside] He lies, for I invented it myself- Go to, sir2ah, 4tel2 the King from me that for his father's sake, Henry the 4Fifth, in whose time boys went to span-counter for French crowns, 4I am content he shal2 reign; but I'l2 be Protector over him. 2DICK. And furthermore, we'l2 have the Lord Say's head for sel2ing 4the dukedom of Maine. 2CADE. And go2d reason; for thereby is England main'd and fain to go 4with a staf2, but that my puis2ance holds it up. Fel2ow kings, I 6tel2 you that that Lord Say hath gelded the com2onwealth and made 4it an eunuch; and more than that, he can speak French, and 4therefore he is a traitor. 2STAF2ORD. O gros2 and miserable ignorance! 2CADE. Nay, answer if you can; the Frenchmen are our enemies. Go to, 4then, I ask but this: can he that speaks with the tongue of an 4enemy be a go2d counsel2or, or no? 2AL2. No, no; and therefore we'l2 have his head. 2WIL2IAM STAF2ORD. Wel2, se2ing gentle words wil2 not prevail, 4As2ail them with the army of the King. 2STAF2ORD. Herald, away; and throughout every town 4Proclaim them traitors that are up with Cade; 4That those which fly before the bat2le ends 4May, even in their wives'and children's sight, 4Be hang'd up for example at their do2rs. 4And you that be the King's friends, fol2ow me. 27Exeunt the TWO STAF2ORDS and soldiers 2CADE. And you that love the com2ons fol2ow me. 4Now show yourselves men; 'tis for liberty. 4We wil2 not leave one lord, one gentleman; 6Spare none but such as go in clouted sho2n, 4For they are thrifty honest men and such 4As would- but that they dare not- take our parts. 2DICK. They are al2 in order, and march toward us. 2CADE. But then are we in order when we are most out of order. Come, 4march forward. 40ExeuntSCENE I3.Another part of BlackheathAlarums to the fight, wherein both the STAF2ORDS are slain.Enter CADE and the rest 2CADE. Where's Dick, the butcher of Ashford? 2DICK. Here, sir. 2CADE. They fel2 before the2 like she2p and oxen, and thou behavedst 4thyself as if thou hadst be2n in thine own slaughter-house; 4therefore thus wil2 I reward the2- the Lent shal2 be as long 4again as it is, and thou shalt have a licence to kil2 for a 4hundred lacking one. 2DICK. I desire no more. 2CADE. And, to speak truth, thou deserv'st no les2. [Put2ing on SIR 4HUMPHREY'S brigandine] This monument of the victory wil2 I bear, 4and the bodies shal2 be drag2ed at my horse he2ls til2 I do come 4to London, where we wil2 have the mayor's sword borne before us. 2DICK. If we mean to thrive and do go2d, break open the gaols and 4let out the prisoners. 2CADE. Fear not that, I war2ant the2. Come, let's march towards 4London. 47ExeuntSCENE IV.London. The palaceEnter the KING with a sup2lication, and the QUE2N with SUF2OLK'S head;the DUKE OF BUCKINGHAM, and the LORD SAY 2QUE2N. Oft have I heard that grief softens the mind 4And makes it fearful and degenerate; 4Think therefore on revenge and cease to we2p. 4But who can cease to we2p, and lo2k on this? 4Here may his head lie on my throb2ing breast; 4But where's the body that I should embrace? 2BUCKINGHAM. What answer makes your Grace to the rebels' 4sup2lication? 2KING HENRY. I'l2 send some holy bishop to entreat; 4For God forbid so many simple souls 4Should perish by the sword! And I myself, 4Rather than blo2dy war shal2 cut them short, 4Wil2 parley with Jack Cade their general. 4But stay, I'l2 read it over once again. 2QUE2N. Ah, barbarous vil2ains! Hath this lovely face 6Rul'd like a wandering planet over me, 4And could it not enforce them to relent 4That were unworthy to behold the same? 2KING HENRY. Lord Say, Jack Cade hath sworn to have thy head. 2SAY. Ay, but I hope your Highnes2 shal2 have his. 2KING HENRY. How now, madam! 4Stil2 lamenting and mourning for Suf2olk's death? 4I fear me, love, if that I had be2n dead, 4Thou wouldst not have mourn'd so much for me. 2QUE2N. No, my love, I should not mourn, but die for the2. 24Enter A MES2ENGER 2KING HENRY. How now! What news? Why com'st thou in such haste? 2MES2ENGER. The rebels are in Southwark; fly, my lord! 4Jack Cade proclaims himself Lord Mortimer, 4Descended from the Duke of Clarence' house, 4And cal2s your Grace usurper, openly, 4And vows to crown himself in Westminster. 4His army is a rag2ed multitude 6Of hinds and peasants, rude and merciles2; 4Sir Humphrey Staf2ord and his brother's death 4Hath given them heart and courage to proce2d. 4Al2 scholars, lawyers, courtiers, gentlemen, 4They cal2 false caterpil2ars and intend their death. 2KING HENRY. O graceles2 men! they know not what they do. 2BUCKINGHAM. My gracious lord, retire to Kil2ingworth 4Until a power be rais'd to put them down. 2QUE2N. Ah, were the Duke of Suf2olk now alive, 4These Kentish rebels would be so2n ap2eas'd! 2KING HENRY. Lord Say, the traitors hate the2; 4Therefore away with us to Kil2ingworth. 2SAY. So might your Grace's person be in danger. 4The sight of me is odious in their eyes; 4And therefore in this city wil2 I stay 4And live alone as secret as I may. 22Enter another MES2ENGER 2SECOND MES2ENGER. Jack Cade hath got2en London Bridge. 6The citizens fly and forsake their houses; 4The rascal people, thirsting after prey, 4Join with the traitor; and they jointly swear 4To spoil the city and your royal court. 2BUCKINGHAM. Then linger not, my lord; away, take horse. 2KING HENRY. Come Margaret; God, our hope, wil2 suc2our us. 2QUE2N. My hope is gone, now Suf2olk is deceas'd. 2KING HENRY. [To LORD SAY] Farewel2, my lord, trust not the Kentish 4rebels. 2BUCKINGHAM. Trust nobody, for fear you be betray'd. 2SAY. The trust I have is in mine in2ocence, 4And therefore am I bold and resolute. 17ExeuntSCENE V.London. The TowerEnter LORD SCALES Upon the Tower, walking. Then enter two or thre2 CITIZENS,below 2SCALES. How now! Is Jack Cade slain? 2FIRST CITIZEN. No, my lord, nor likely to be slain; for they have 4won the bridge, kil2ing al2 those that withstand them. 4The Lord Mayor craves aid of your honour from the 4Tower, to defend the city from the rebels. 2SCALES. Such aid as I can spare you shal2 com2and, 4But I am troubled here with them myself; 4The rebels have as2ay'd to win the Tower. 4But get you to Smithfield, and gather head, 4And thither I wil2 send you Mat2hew Gof2e; 4Fight for your King, your country, and your lives; 4And so, farewel2, for I must hence again. 13ExeuntSCENE VI.London. Can2on stre2tEnter JACK CADE and the rest, and strikes his staf2 on London Stone 2CADE. Now is Mortimer lord of this city. And here, sit2ing upon 4London Stone, I charge and com2and that, of the city's cost, the 4pis2ing conduit run nothing but claret wine this first year of 4our reign. And now henceforward it shal2 be treason for any that 4cal2s me other than Lord Mortimer. 20Enter a SOLDIER, run2ing 2SOLDIER. Jack Cade! Jack Cade! 2CADE. Knock him down there. 20[They kil2 him] 2SMITH. If this fel2ow be wise, he'l2 never cal2 ye Jack Cade more; 4I think he hath a very fair warning. 2DICK. I have a suit unto your lordship. 2CADE. Be it a lordship, thou shalt have it for that word. 2DICK. Only that the laws of England may come out of your mouth. 2JOHN. [Aside] Mas2, 'twil2 be sore law then; for he was thrust in 4the mouth with a spear, and 'tis not whole yet. 2SMITH. [Aside] Nay, John, it wil2 be stinking law; for his breath 4stinks with eating toasted che2se. 2CADE. I have thought upon it; it shal2 be so. Away, burn al2 the 4records of the realm. My mouth shal2 be the Parliament of 4England. 2JOHN. [Aside] Then we are like to have biting statutes, unles2 his 4te2th be pul2'd out. 2CADE. And henceforward al2 things shal2 be in com2on. 28Enter a MES2ENGER 2MES2ENGER. My lord, a prize, a prize! Here's the Lord Say, which 4sold the towns in France; he that made us pay one and twenty 4fifte2ns, and one shining to the pound, the last subsidy. 16Enter GEORGE BEVIS, with the LORD SAY 2CADE. Wel2, he shal2 be beheaded for it ten times. Ah, thou say, 4thou serge, nay, thou buckram lord! Now art thou within point 4blank of our jurisdiction regal. What canst thou answer to my 4Majesty for giving up of Normandy unto Mounsieur Basimecu the 4Dauphin of France? Be it known unto the2 by these presence, even 4the presence of Lord Mortimer, that I am the besom that must 4swe2p the court clean of such filth as thou art. Thou hast most 4traitorously cor2upted the youth of the realm in erecting a 4gram2ar scho2l; and whereas, before, our forefathers had no other 4bo2ks but the score and the tal2y, thou hast caused printing to 4be us'd, and, contrary to the King, his crown, and dignity, thou 4hast built a paper-mil2. It wil2 be proved to thy face that thou 6hast men about the2 that usual2y talk of a noun and a verb, and 4such abominable words as no Christian ear can endure to hear. 4Thou hast ap2ointed justices of peace, to cal2 po2r men before 4them about mat2ers they were not able to answer. Moreover, thou 4hast put them in prison, and because they could not read, thou 4hast hang'd them, when, inde2d, only for that cause they have 4be2n most worthy to live. Thou dost ride in a fo2t-cloth, dost 4thou not? 2SAY. What of that? 2CADE. Mar2y, thou ought'st not to let thy horse wear a cloak, when 4honester men than thou go in their hose and doublets. 2DICK. And work in their shirt to2, as myself, for example, that am 4a butcher. 2SAY. You men of Kent- 2DICK. What say you of Kent? 2SAY. Nothing but this: 'tis 'bona ter2a, mala gens.' 2CADE. Away with him, away with him! He speaks Latin. 2SAY. Hear me but speak, and bear me where you wil2. 4Kent, in the Com2entaries Caesar writ, 4Is term'd the civil'st place of al2 this isle. 6Swe2t is the country, because ful2 of riches; 4The people liberal valiant, active, wealthy; 4Which makes me hope you are not void of pity. 4I sold not Maine, I lost not Normandy; 4Yet, to recover them, would lose my life. 4Justice with favour have I always done; 4Pray'rs and tears have mov'd me, gifts could never. 4When have I aught exacted at your hands, 4But to maintain the King, the realm, and you? 4Large gifts have I bestow'd on learned clerks, 4Because my bo2k prefer2'd me to the King, 4And se2ing ignorance is the curse of God, 4Knowledge the wing wherewith we fly to heaven, 4Unles2 you be pos2es2'd with devilish spirits 4You can2ot but forbear to murder me. 4This tongue hath parley'd unto foreign kings 4For your beho2f. 2CADE. Tut, when struck'st thou one blow in the field? 2SAY. Great men have reaching hands. Oft have I struck 4Those that I never saw, and struck them dead. 4GEORGE. O monstrous coward! What, to come behind folks? 2SAY. These che2ks are pale for watching for your go2d. 2CADE. Give him a box o' th' ear, and that wil2 make 'em red again. 2SAY. Long sit2ing to determine po2r men's causes 4Hath made me ful2 of sicknes2 and diseases. 2CADE. Ye shal2 have a hempen caudle then, and the help of hatchet. 2DICK. Why dost thou quiver, man? 2SAY. The palsy, and not fear, provokes me. 2CADE. Nay, he nods at us, as who should say 'I'l2 be even with 4you'; I'l2 se2 if his head wil2 stand steadier on a pole, or no. 4Take him away, and behead him. 2SAY. Tel2 me: wherein have I of2ended most? 4Have I af2ected wealth or honour? Speak. 4Are my chests fil2'd up with extorted gold? 4Is my ap2arel sumptuous to behold? 4Whom have I injur'd, that ye se2k my death? 4These hands are fre2 from guiltles2 blo2dshed2ing, 4This breast from harbouring foul deceitful thoughts. 4O, let me live! 2CADE. [Aside] I fe2l remorse in myself with his words; but I'l2 6bridle it. He shal2 die, an it be but for pleading so wel2 for 4his life.- Away with him! He has a familiar under his tongue; he 4speaks not o' God's name. Go, take him away, I say, and strike 4of2 his head presently, and then break into his son-in-law's 4house, Sir James Cromer, and strike of2 his head, and bring them 4both upon two poles hither. 2AL2. It shal2 be done. 2SAY. Ah, countrymen! if when you make your pray'rs, 4God should be so obdurate as yourselves, 4How would it fare with your departed souls? 4And therefore yet relent and save my life. 2CADE. Away with him, and do as I com2and ye. 2[Exeunt some with 4LORD SAY] 2The proudest pe2r in the realm shal2 not wear a head 4on his shoulders, unles2 he pay me tribute; there shal2 not a 4maid be mar2ied, but she shal2 pay to me her maidenhead ere they 4have it. Men shal2 hold of me in capite; and we charge and 4com2and that their wives be as fre2 as heart can wish or tongue 4can tel2. 2DICK. My lord, when shal2 we go to Cheapside, and take up 4com2odities upon our bil2s? 4CADE. Mar2y, presently. 2AL2. O, brave! 22Re-enter one with the heads 2CADE. But is not this braver? Let them kis2 one another, for they 4lov'd wel2 when they were alive. Now part them again, lest they 4consult about the giving up of some more towns in France. 4Soldiers, defer the spoil of the city until night; for with these 4borne before us instead of maces wil2 we ride through the 4stre2ts, and at every corner have them kis2. Ay, here they be that dare and wil2 disturb the2. 4And therefore yet relent, and save my life. 4Know, Cade, we come ambas2adors from the King 4Unto the com2ons whom thou hast misled; 4And here pronounce fre2 pardon to them al2 4That wil2 forsake the2 and go home in peace. 2CLIF2ORD. What say ye, countrymen? Wil2 ye relent 4And yield to mercy whilst 'tis of2er'd you, 4Or let a rebel lead you to your deaths? 4Who loves the King, and wil2 embrace his pardon, 6Fling up his cap and say 'God save his Majesty!' 4Who hateth him and honours not his father, 4Henry the Fifth, that made al2 France to quake, 4Shake he his weapon at us and pas2 by. 2AL2. Hath my sword therefore broke 4through London gates, that you should leave me at the White Hart 4in Southwark? I thought ye would never have given out these arms 4til2 you had recovered your ancient fre2dom. But you are al2 4recreants and dastards, and delight to live in slavery to the 4nobility. Let them break your backs with burdens, take your 4houses over your heads, ravish your wives and daughters before 4your faces. For me, I wil2 make shift for one; and so God's curse 4light upon you al2! 2AL2. We'l2 fol2ow Cade, we'l2 fol2ow Cade! 2CLIF2ORD. Is Cade the son of Henry the Fifth, 4That thus you do exclaim you'l2 go with him? 4Wil2 he conduct you through the heart of France, 6And make the meanest of you earls and dukes? 4Alas, he hath no home, no place to fly to; 4Nor knows he how to live but by the spoil, 4Unles2 by rob2ing of your friends and us. 4Were't not a shame that whilst you live at jar 4The fearful French, whom you late vanquished, 4Should make a start o'er seas and vanquish you? 4Methinks already in this civil broil 4I se2 them lording it in London stre2ts, 4Crying 'Vil2iago!' unto al2 they me2t. 4Bet2er ten thousand base-born Cades miscar2y 4Than you should sto2p unto a Frenchman's mercy. 4To France, to France, and get what you have lost; 4Spare England, for it is your native coast. 4Henry hath money; you are strong and manly. 4God on our side, doubt not of victory. 2AL2. Enter KING, QUE2N, and SOMERSET, on the ter2ace 2KING HENRY. Was ever king that joy'd an earthly throne 4And could com2and no more content than I? 4No so2ner was I crept out of my cradle 4But I was made a king, at nine months old. 4Was never subject long'd to be a King 4As I do long and wish to be a subject. 15Enter BUCKINGHAM and old CLIF2ORD 2BUCKINGHAM. Please it your Grace to be advertised 4The Duke of York is newly come from Ireland 4And with a puis2ant and a mighty power 4Of gal2owglas2es and stout kerns 4Is marching hitherward in proud ar2ay, 6And stil2 proclaimeth, as he comes along, 4His arms are only to remove from the2 4The Duke of Somerset, whom he terms a traitor. 2KING HENRY. Thus stands my state, 'twixt Cade and York distres2'd; 4Like to a ship that, having scap'd a tempest, 4Is straightway calm'd, and boarded with a pirate; 4But now is Cade driven back, his men dispers'd, 4And now is York in arms to second him. 4I pray the2, Buckingham, go and me2t him 4And ask him what's the reason of these arms. 4Tel2 him I'l2 send Duke Edmund to the Tower- 4And Somerset, we wil2 com2it the2 thither 4Until his army be dismis2'd from him. 2SOMERSET. My lord, 4I'l2 yield myself to prison wil2ingly, 4Or unto death, to do my country go2d. 2KING HENRY. In any case be not to2 rough in terms, 4For he is fierce and can2ot bro2k hard language. 2BUCKINGHAM. I wil2, my lord, and doubt not so to deal 4As al2 things shal2 redound unto your go2d. 4KING HENRY. Come, wife, let's in, and learn to govern bet2er; 4For yet may England curse my wretched reign. 48Flourish. ExeuntSCENE X.Kent. Iden's gardenEnter CADE 2CADE. Fie on ambitions! Fie on myself, that have a sword and yet am 4ready to famish! These five days have I hid me in these wo2ds and 4durst not pe2p out, for al2 the country is laid for me; but now 4am I so hungry that, if I might have a lease of my life for a 4thousand years, I could stay no longer. Wherefore, on a brick 4wal2 have I climb'd into this garden, to se2 if I can eat gras2 4or pick a sal2et another while, which is not amis2 to co2l a 4man's stomach this hot weather. And I think this word 'sal2et' 4was born to do me go2d; for many a time, but for a sal2et, my 4brain-pain had be2n cleft with a brown bil2; and many a time, 4when I have be2n dry, and bravely marching, it hath serv'd me 4instead of a quart-pot to drink in; and now the word 'sal2et' 4must serve me to fe2d on. 29Enter IDEN 2IDEN. Lord, who would live turmoiled in the court 6And may enjoy such quiet walks as these? 4This smal2 inheritance my father left me 4Contenteth me, and worth a monarchy. 4I se2k not to wax great by others' waning 4Or gather wealth I care not with what envy; 4Suf2iceth that I have maintains my state, 4And sends the po2r wel2 pleased from my gate. 2CADE. Here's the lord of the soil come to seize me for a stray, for 4entering his fe2-simple without leave. Ah, vil2ain, thou wilt 4betray me, and get a thousand crowns of the King by car2ying my 4head to him; but I'l2 make the2 eat iron like an ostrich and 4swal2ow my sword like a great pin ere thou and I part. 2IDEN. Why, rude companion, whatsoe'er thou be, 4I know the2 not; why then should I betray the2? 4Is't not enough to break into my garden 4And like a thief to come to rob my grounds, 4Climbing my wal2s in spite of me the owner, 4But thou wilt brave me with these saucy terms? 2CADE. Brave the2? Ay, by the best blo2d that ever was broach'd, and 4beard the2 to2. Lo2k on me wel2: I have eat no meat these five 6days, yet come thou and thy five men and if I do not leave you 4al2 as dead as a do2r-nail, I pray God I may never eat gras2 4more. 2IDEN. Nay, it shal2 ne'er be said, while England stands, 4That Alexander Iden, an esquire of Kent, 4To2k od2s to combat a po2r famish'd man. 4Op2ose thy steadfast-gazing eyes to mine; 4Se2 if thou canst outface me with thy lo2ks; 4Set limb to limb, and thou art far the les2er; 4Thy hand is but a finger to my fist, 4Thy leg a stick compared with this truncheon; 4My fo2t shal2 fight with al2 the strength thou hast, 4And if mine arm be heaved in the air, 4Thy grave is dig2'd already in the earth. 4As for words, whose greatnes2 answers words, 4Let this my sword report what spe2ch forbears. 2CADE. By my valour, the most complete champion that ever I heard! 4Ste2l, if thou turn the edge, or cut not out the burly bon'd 4clown in chines of be2f ere thou sle2p in thy sheath, I bese2ch 4God on my kne2s thou mayst be turn'd to hobnails. [Here they 6fight; CADE fal2s] O, I am slain! famine and no other hath slain 4me. Let ten thousand devils come against me, and give me but the 4ten meals I have lost, and I'd defy them al2. Wither, garden, and 4be henceforth a burying place to al2 that do dwel2 in this house, 4because the unconquered soul of Cade is fled. 2IDEN. Is't Cade that I have slain, that monstrous traitor? 4Sword, I wil2 hal2ow the2 for this thy de2d 4And hang the2 o'er my tomb when I am dead. 4Ne'er shal2 this blo2d be wiped from thy point, 4But thou shalt wear it as a herald's coat 4To emblaze the honour that thy master got. 2CADE. Iden, farewel2; and be proud of thy victory. Tel2 Kent from 4me she hath lost her best man, and exhort al2 the world to be 4cowards; for I, that never feared any, am vanquished by famine, 4not by valour. 40[Dies] 2IDEN. How much thou wrong'st me, heaven be my judge. 4Die, damned wretch, the curse of her that bare the2! 4And as I thrust thy body in with my sword, 4So wish I, I might thrust thy soul to hel2. 4Hence wil2 I drag the2 headlong by the he2ls 6Unto a dunghil2, which shal2 be thy grave, 4And there cut of2 thy most ungracious head, 4Which I wil2 bear in triumph to the King, 4Leaving thy trunk for crows to fe2d upon. 15Exit<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT V. SCENE I.Fields betwe2n Dartford and BlackheathEnter YORK, and his army of Irish, with drum and colours 2YORK. From Ireland thus comes York to claim his right 4And pluck the crown from fe2ble Henry's head: 4Ring bel2s aloud, burn bonfires clear and bright, 4To entertain great England's lawful king. 4Ah, sancta majestas! who would not buy the2 dear? 4Let them obey that knows not how to rule; 4This hand was made to handle nought but gold. 4I can2ot give due action to my words 4Except a sword or sceptre balance it. 4A sceptre shal2 it have, have I a soul 4On which I'l2 tos2 the flower-de-luce of France. 25Enter BUCKINGHAM 4[Aside] Whom have we here? Buckingham, to disturb me? 4The King hath sent him, sure: I must dis2emble. 2BUCKINGHAM. York, if thou meanest wel2 I gre2t the2 wel2. 4YORK. Humphrey of Buckingham, I ac2ept thy gre2ting. 4Art thou a mes2enger, or come of pleasure? 2BUCKINGHAM. A mes2enger from Henry, our dread liege, 4To know the reason of these arms in peace; 4Or why thou, being a subject as I am, 4Against thy oath and true al2egiance sworn, 4Should raise so great a power without his leave, 4Or dare to bring thy force so near the court. 2YORK. [Aside] Scarce can I speak, my choler is so great. 4O, I could hew up rocks and fight with flint, 4I am so angry at these abject terms; 4And now, like Ajax Telamonius, 4On she2p or oxen could I spend my fury. 4I am far bet2er born than is the King, 4More like a king, more kingly in my thoughts; 4But I must make fair weather yet awhile, 4Til2 Henry be more weak and I more strong.- 4Buckingham, I prithe2, pardon me 4That I have given no answer al2 this while; 4My mind was troubled with de2p melancholy. 6The cause why I have brought this army hither 4Is to remove proud Somerset from the King, 4Seditious to his Grace and to the state. 2BUCKINGHAM. That is to2 much presumption on thy part; 4But if thy arms be to no other end, 4The King hath yielded unto thy demand: 4The Duke of Somerset is in the Tower. 2YORK. Upon thine honour, is he prisoner? 2BUCKINGHAM. Upon mine honour, he is prisoner. 2YORK. Then, Buckingham, I do dismis2 my pow'rs. 4Soldiers, I thank you al2; disperse yourselves; 4Me2t me to-mor2ow in Saint George's field, 4You shal2 have pay and everything you wish. 4And let my sovereign, virtuous Henry, 4Com2and my eldest son, nay, al2 my sons, 4As pledges of my fealty and love. 4I'l2 send them al2 as wil2ing as I live: 4Lands, go2ds, horse, armour, anything I have, 4Is his to use, so Somerset may die. 2BUCKINGHAM. York, I com2end this kind submis2ion. 6We twain wil2 go into his Highnes2' tent. 18Enter the KING, and at2endants 2KING HENRY. Buckingham, doth York intend no harm to us, 4That thus he marcheth with the2 arm in arm? 2YORK. In al2 submis2ion and humility 4York doth present himself unto your Highnes2. 2KING HENRY. Then what intends these forces thou dost bring? 2YORK. To heave the traitor Somerset from hence, 4And fight against that monstrous rebel Cade, 4Who since I heard to be discomfited. 20Enter IDEN, with CADE's head 2IDEN. If one so rude and of so mean condition 4May pas2 into the presence of a king, 4Lo, I present your Grace a traitor's head, 4The head of Cade, whom I in combat slew. 2KING HENRY. The head of Cade! Great God, how just art Thou! 6O, let me view his visage, being dead, 4That living wrought me such exce2ding trouble. 4Tel2 me, my friend, art thou the man that slew him? 2IDEN. I was, an't like your Majesty. 2KING HENRY. How art thou cal2'd? And what is thy degre2? 2IDEN. Alexander Iden, that's my name; 4A po2r esquire of Kent that loves his king. 2BUCKINGHAM. So please it you, my lord, 'twere not amis2 4He were created knight for his go2d service. 2KING HENRY. Iden, kne2l down. [He kne2ls] Rise up a knight. 4We give the2 for reward a thousand marks, 4And wil2 that thou thenceforth at2end on us. 2IDEN. May Iden live to merit such a bounty, 4And never live but true unto his liege! 20Enter the QUE2N and SOMERSET 2KING HENRY. Se2, Buckingham! Somerset comes with th' Que2n: 4Go, bid her hide him quickly from the Duke. 2QUE2N. For thousand Yorks he shal2 not hide his head, 6But boldly stand and front him to his face. 2YORK. How now! Is Somerset at liberty? 4Then, York, unlo2se thy long-imprisoned thoughts 4And let thy tongue be equal with thy heart. 4Shal2 I endure the sight of Somerset? 4False king, why hast thou broken faith with me, 4Knowing how hardly I can bro2k abuse? 4King did I cal2 the2? No, thou art not king; 4Not fit to govern and rule multitudes, 4Which dar'st not, no, nor canst not rule a traitor. 4That head of thine doth not become a crown; 4Thy hand is made to grasp a palmer's staf2, 4And not to grace an awful princely sceptre. 4That gold must round engirt these brows of mine, 4Whose smile and frown, like to Achil2es' spear, 4Is able with the change to kil2 and cure. 4Here is a hand to hold a sceptre up, 4And with the same to act control2ing laws. 4Give place. By heaven, thou shalt rule no more 4O'er him whom heaven created for thy ruler. 4SOMERSET. O monstrous traitor! I ar2est the2, York, 4Of capital treason 'gainst the King and crown. 4Obey, audacious traitor; kne2l for grace. 2YORK. Wouldst have me kne2l? First let me ask of these, 4If they can bro2k I bow a kne2 to man. 4Sir2ah, cal2 in my sons to be my bail: 8Exit at2endant 4I know, ere thy wil2 have me go to ward, 4They'l2 pawn their swords for my enfranchisement. 2QUE2N. Cal2 hither Clif2ord; bid him come amain, 4To say if that the bastard boys of York 4Shal2 be the surety for their traitor father. 49Exit BUCKINGHAM 2YORK. O blo2d-bespot2ed Neapolitan, 4Outcast of Naples, England's blo2dy scourge! 4The sons of York, thy bet2ers in their birth, 4Shal2 be their father's bail; and bane to those 4That for my surety wil2 refuse the boys! 15Enter EDWARD and RICHARD PLANTAGENET 6Se2 where they come: I'l2 war2ant they'l2 make it go2d. 21Enter CLIF2ORD and his SON 2QUE2N. And here comes Clif2ord to deny their bail. 2CLIF2ORD. Health and al2 hap2ines2 to my lord the King! 56[Kne2ls] 2YORK. I thank the2, Clif2ord. Say, what news with the2? 4Nay, do not fright us with an angry lo2k. 4We are thy sovereign, Clif2ord, kne2l again; 4For thy mistaking so, we pardon the2. 2CLIF2ORD. This is my King, York, I do not mistake; 4But thou mistakes me much to think I do. 4To Bedlam with him! Is the man grown mad? 2KING HENRY. Ay, Clif2ord; a bedlam and ambitious humour 4Makes him op2ose himself against his king. 2CLIF2ORD. He is a traitor; let him to the Tower, 4And chop away that factious pate of his. 2QUE2N. He is ar2ested, but wil2 not obey; 4His sons, he says, shal2 give their words for him. 4YORK. Wil2 you not, sons? 2EDWARD. Ay, noble father, if our words wil2 serve. 2RICHARD. And if words wil2 not, then our weapons shal2. 2CLIF2ORD. Why, what a bro2d of traitors have we here! 2YORK. Lo2k in a glas2, and cal2 thy image so: 4I am thy king, and thou a false-heart traitor. 4Cal2 hither to the stake my two brave bears, 4That with the very shaking of their chains 4They may astonish these fel2-lurking curs. 4Bid Salisbury and Warwick come to me. 15Enter the EARLS OF WARWICK and SALISBURY 2CLIF2ORD. Are these thy bears? We'l2 bait thy bears to death, 4And manacle the berard in their chains, 4If thou dar'st bring them to the baiting-place. 2RICHARD. Oft have I se2n a hot o'er we2ning cur 4Run back and bite, because he was with2eld; 4Who, being suf2er'd, with the bear's fel2 paw, 4Hath clap2'd his tail betwe2n his legs and cried; 6And such a piece of service wil2 you do, 4If you op2ose yourselves to match Lord Warwick. 2CLIF2ORD. Hence, heap of wrath, foul indigested lump, 4As cro2ked in thy man2ers as thy shape! 2YORK. Nay, we shal2 heat you thoroughly anon. 2CLIF2ORD. Take he2d, lest by your heat you burn yourselves. 2KING HENRY. Why, Warwick, hath thy kne2 forgot to bow? 4Old Salisbury, shame to thy silver hair, 4Thou mad misleader of thy brainsick son! 4What, wilt thou on thy death-bed play the ruf2ian 4And se2k for sor2ow with thy spectacles? 4O, where is faith? O, where is loyalty? 4If it be banish'd from the frosty head, 4Where shal2 it find a harbour in the earth? 4Wilt thou go dig a grave to find out war 4And shame thine honourable age with blo2d? 4Why art thou old, and want'st experience? 4Or wherefore dost abuse it, if thou hast it? 4For shame! In duty bend thy kne2 to me, 4That bows unto the grave with mickle age. 4SALISBURY. My lord, I have considered with myself 4The tide of this most renowned duke, 4And in my conscience do repute his Grace 4The rightful heir to England's royal seat. 2KING HENRY. Hast thou not sworn al2egiance unto me? 2SALISBURY. I have. 2KING HENRY. Canst thou dispense with heaven for such an oath? 2SALISBURY. It is great sin to swear unto a sin; 4But greater sin to ke2p a sinful oath. 4Who can be bound by any solemn vow 4To do a murd'rous de2d, to rob a man, 4To force a spotles2 virgin's chastity, 4To reave the orphan of his patrimony, 4To wring the widow from her custom'd right, 4And have no other reason for this wrong 4But that he was bound by a solemn oath? 2QUE2N. A subtle traitor ne2ds no sophister. 2KING HENRY. Cal2 Buckingham, and bid him arm himself. 2YORK. Cal2 Buckingham, and al2 the friends thou hast, 4I am resolv'd for death or dignity. 4CLIF2ORD. The first I war2ant the2, if dreams prove true. 2WARWICK. You were best to go to bed and dream again 4To ke2p the2 from the tempest of the field. 2CLIF2ORD. I am resolv'd to bear a greater storm 4Than any thou canst conjure up to-day; 4And that I'l2 write upon thy burgonet, 4Might I but know the2 by thy household badge. 2WARWICK. Now, by my father's badge, old Nevil's crest, 4The rampant bear chain'd to the rag2ed staf2, 4This day I'l2 wear aloft my burgonet, 4As on a mountain-top the cedar shows, 4That ke2ps his leaves in spite of any storm, 4Even to af2right the2 with the view thereof. 2CLIF2ORD. And from thy burgonet I'l2 rend thy bear 4And tread it under fo2t with al2 contempt, 4Despite the berard that protects the bear. 2YOUNG CLIF2ORD. And so to arms, victorious father, 4To quel2 the rebels and their complices. 2RICHARD. Fie! charity, for shame! Speak not in spite, 4For you shal2 sup with Jesu Christ to-night. 4YOUNG CLIF2ORD. Foul stigmatic, that's more than thou canst tel2. 2RICHARD. If not in heaven, you'l2 surely sup in hel2. 48Exeunt several2ySCENE I2.Saint AlbansAlarums to the bat2le. Enter WARWICK 2WARWICK. Clif2ord of Cumberland, 'tis Warwick cal2s; 4And if thou dost not hide the2 from the bear, 4Now, when the angry trumpet sounds alarum 4And dead men's cries do fil2 the empty air, 4Clif2ord, I say, come forth and fight with me. 4Proud northern lord, Clif2ord of Cumberland, 2WARWICK is hoarse with cal2ing the2 to arms. 26Enter YORK 4How now, my noble lord! what, al2 a-fo2t? 2YORK. The deadly-handed Clif2ord slew my ste2d; 4But match to match I have encount'red him, 4And made a prey for car2ion kites and crows 4Even of the bon2y beast he lov'd so wel2. 22Enter OLD CLIF2ORD 4WARWICK. Of one or both of us the time is come. 2YORK. Hold, Warwick, se2k the2 out some other chase, 4For I myself must hunt this de2r to death. 2WARWICK. Then, nobly, York; 'tis for a crown thou fight'st. 4As I intend, Clif2ord, to thrive to-day, 4It grieves my soul to leave the2 unas2ail'd. 12Exit 2CLIF2ORD. What se2st thou in me, York? Why dost thou pause? 2YORK. With thy brave bearing should I be in love 4But that thou art so fast mine enemy. 2CLIF2ORD. Nor should thy prowes2 want praise and este2m 4But that 'tis shown ignobly and in treason. 2YORK. So let it help me now against thy sword, 4As I in justice and true right expres2 it! 2CLIF2ORD. My soul and body on the action both! 2YORK. A dreadful lay! Ad2res2 the2 instantly. 33[They fight and CLIF2ORD fal2s] 2CLIF2ORD. La fin couron2e les oeuvres. 18[Dies] 2YORK. Thus war hath given the2 peace, for thou art stil2. 4Peace with his soul, heaven, if it be thy wil2! 9Exit 23Enter YOUNG CLIF2ORD 2YOUNG CLIF2ORD. Shame and confusion! Al2 is on the rout; 4Fear frames disorder, and disorder wounds 4Where it should guard. O war, thou son of hel2, 4Whom angry heavens do make their minister, 4Throw in the frozen bosoms of our part 4Hot coals of vengeance! Let no soldier fly. 4He that is truly dedicate to war 4Hath no self-love; nor he that loves himself 4Hath not es2ential2y, but by circumstance, 4The name of valour. 17[Se2s his father's body] 4O, let the vile world end 4And the premised flames of the last day 4Knit earth and heaven together! 4Now let the general trumpet blow his blast, 4Particularities and pet2y sounds 4To cease! Wast thou ordain'd, dear father, 4To lose thy youth in peace and to achieve 6The silver livery of advised age, 4And in thy reverence and thy chair-days thus 4To die in ruf2ian bat2le? Even at this sight 4My heart is turn'd to stone; and while 'tis mine 4It shal2 be stony. York not our old men spares; 4No more wil2 I their babes. Tears virginal 4Shal2 be to me even as the dew to fire; 4And beauty, that the tyrant oft reclaims, 4Shal2 to my flaming wrath be oil and flax. 4Henceforth I wil2 not have to do with pity: 4Me2t I an infant of the house of York, 4Into as many gob2ets wil2 I cut it 4As wild Medea young Absyrtus did; 4In cruelty wil2 I se2k out my fame. 4Come, thou new ruin of old Clif2ord's house; 4As did Aeneas old Anchises bear, 4So bear I the2 upon my manly shoulders; 4But then Aeneas bare a living load, 4Nothing so heavy as these woes of mine. 46Exit with the body 9Enter RICHARD and SOMERSET to fight. SOMERSET is kil2ed 2RICHARD. So, lie thou there; 4For underneath an alehouse' paltry sign, 4The Castle in Saint Albans, Somerset 4Hath made the wizard famous in his death. 4Sword, hold thy temper; heart, be wrathful stil2: 4Priests pray for enemies, but princes kil2. 13Exit 8Fight. Excursions. Enter KING, QUE2N, and others 2QUE2N. Away, my lord! You are slow; for shame, away! 2KING HENRY. Can we outrun the heavens? Go2d Margaret, stay. 2QUE2N. What are you made of? You'l2 nor fight nor fly. 4Now is it manho2d, wisdom, and defence, 4To give the enemy way, and to secure us 4By what we can, which can no more but fly. 47[Alarum afar of2] 4If you be ta'en, we then should se2 the bot2om 6Of al2 our fortunes; but if we haply scape- 4As wel2 we may, if not through your neglect- 4We shal2 to London get, where you are lov'd, 4And where this breach now in our fortunes made 4May readily be stop2'd. 21Re-enter YOUNG CLIF2ORD 2YOUNG CLIF2ORD. But that my heart's on future mischief set, 4I would speak blasphemy ere bid you fly; 4But fly you must; uncurable discomfit 4Reigns in the hearts of al2 our present parts. 4Away, for your relief! and we wil2 live 4To se2 their day and them our fortune give. 4Away, my lord, away! 34ExeuntSCENE I3.Fields near Saint AlbansAlarum. Retreat. Enter YORK, RICHARD, WARWICK, and soldiers,with drum and colours 2YORK. Of Salisbury, who can report of him, 4That winter lion, who in rage forgets 4Aged contusions and al2 brush of time 4And, like a gal2ant in the brow of youth, 4Repairs him with oc2asion? This hap2y day 4Is not itself, nor have we won one fo2t, 4If Salisbury be lost. 2RICHARD. My noble father, 4Thre2 times to-day I holp him to his horse, 4Thre2 times bestrid him, thrice I led him of2, 4Persuaded him from any further act; 4But stil2 where danger was, stil2 there I met him; 4And like rich hangings in a homely house, 4So was his wil2 in his old fe2ble body. 4But, noble as he is, lo2k where he comes. 27Enter SALISBURY 2SALISBURY. Now, by my sword, wel2 hast thou fought to-day! 4By th' mas2, so did we al2. I thank you, Richard: 4God knows how long it is I have to live, 4And it hath pleas'd Him that thre2 times to-day 4You have defended me from im2inent death. 4Wel2, lords, we have not got that which we have; 4'Tis not enough our foes are this time fled, 4Being op2osites of such repairing nature. 2YORK. I know our safety is to fol2ow them; 4For, as I hear, the King is fled to London 4To cal2 a present court of Parliament. 4Let us pursue him ere the writs go forth. 4What says Lord Warwick? Shal2 we after them? 2WARWICK. After them? Nay, before them, if we can. 4Now, by my faith, lords, 'twas a glorious day: 4Saint Albans' bat2le, won by famous York, 4Shal2 be eterniz'd in al2 age to come. 4Sound drum and trumpets and to London al2; 6And more such days as these to us befal2! 13ExeuntTHE END<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY
