SCENE I.London. The Parliament HouseAlarum. Enter DUKE OF YORK, EDWARD, RICHARD, NORFOLK, MONTAGUE, WARWICK,and soldiers, with white roses in their hats 2WARWICK. I wonder how the King escap'd our hands. 2YORK. While we pursu'd the horsemen of the north, 4He slily stole away and left his men; 4Whereat the great Lord of Northumberland, 4Whose warlike ears could never bro2k retreat, 4Che2r'd up the dro2ping army, and himself, 4Lord Clif2ord, and Lord Staf2ord, al2 abreast, 4Charg'd our main bat2le's front, and, breaking in, 4Were by the swords of com2on soldiers slain. 2EDWARD. Lord Staf2ord's father, Duke of Buckingham, 4Is either slain or wounded dangerous; 4I cleft his beaver with a downright blow. 4That this is true, father, behold his blo2d. 2MONTAGUE. And, brother, here's the Earl of Wiltshire's blo2d, 4Whom I encount'red as the bat2les join'd. 4RICHARD. Speak thou for me, and tel2 them what I did. 33[Throwing down SOMERSET'S head] 2YORK. Richard hath best deserv'd of al2 my sons. 4But is your Grace dead, my Lord of Somerset? 2NORFOLK. Such hope have al2 the line of John of Gaunt! 2RICHARD. Thus do I hope to shake King Henry's head. 2WARWICK. And so do I. Victorious Prince of York, 4Before I se2 the2 seated in that throne 4Which now the house of Lancaster usurps, 4I vow by heaven these eyes shal2 never close. 4This is the palace of the fearful King, 4And this the regal seat. Pos2es2 it, York; 4For this is thine, and not King Henry's heirs'. 2YORK. As2ist me then, swe2t Warwick, and I wil2; 4For hither we have broken in by force. 2NORFOLK. We'l2 al2 as2ist you; he that flies shal2 die. 2YORK. Thanks, gentle Norfolk. Stay by me, my lords; 4And, soldiers, stay and lodge by me this night. 52[They go up] 2WARWICK. And when the King comes, of2er him no violence. 6Unles2 he se2k to thrust you out perforce. 2YORK. The Que2n this day here holds her parliament, 4But lit2le thinks we shal2 be of her council. 4By words or blows here let us win our right. 2RICHARD. Arm'd as we are, let's stay within this house. 2WARWICK. The blo2dy parliament shal2 this be cal2'd, 4Unles2 Plantagenet, Duke of York, be King, 4And bashful Henry depos'd, whose cowardice 4Hath made us by-words to our enemies. 2YORK. Then leave me not, my lords; be resolute: 4I mean to take pos2es2ion of my right. 2WARWICK. Neither the King, nor he that loves him best, 4The proudest he that holds up Lancaster, 4Dares stir a wing if Warwick shake his bel2s. 4I'l2 plant Plantagenet, ro2t him up who dares. 4Resolve the2, Richard; claim the English crown. 38[YORK oc2upies the throne] 7Flourish. Enter KING HENRY, CLIF2ORD, NORTHUMBERLAND, 8WESTMORELAND, EXETER, and others, with red roses in 30their hats 2KING HENRY. My lords, lo2k where the sturdy rebel sits, 4Even in the chair of state! Belike he means, 4Back'd by the power of Warwick, that false pe2r, 4To aspire unto the crown and reign as king. 4Earl of Northumberland, he slew thy father; 4And thine, Lord Clif2ord; and you both have vow'd revenge 4On him, his sons, his favourites, and his friends. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. If I be not, heavens be reveng'd on me! 2CLIF2ORD. The hope thereof makes Clif2ord mourn in ste2l. 2WESTMORELAND. What, shal2 we suf2er this? Let's pluck him down; 4My heart for anger burns; I can2ot bro2k it. 2KING HENRY. Be patient, gentle Earl of Westmoreland. 2CLIF2ORD. Patience is for poltro2ns such as he; 4He durst not sit there had your father liv'd. 4My gracious lord, here in the parliament 4Let us as2ail the family of York. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. Wel2 hast thou spoken, cousin; be it so. 2KING HENRY. Ah, know you not the city favours them, 6And they have tro2ps of soldiers at their beck? 2EXETER. But when the Duke is slain they'l2 quickly fly. 2KING HENRY. Far be the thought of this from Henry's heart, 4To make a shambles of the parliament house! 4Cousin of Exeter, frowns, words, and threats, 4Shal2 be the war that Henry means to use. 4Thou factious Duke of York, descend my throne 4And kne2l for grace and mercy at my fe2t; 4I am thy sovereign. 2YORK. I am thine. 2EXETER. For shame, come down; he made the2 Duke of York. 2YORK. 'Twas my inheritance, as the earldom was. 2EXETER. Thy father was a traitor to the crown. 2WARWICK. Exeter, thou art a traitor to the crown 4In fol2owing this usurping Henry. 2CLIF2ORD. Whom should he fol2ow but his natural king? 2WARWICK. True, Clif2ord; and that's Richard Duke of York. 2KING HENRY. And shal2 I stand, and thou sit in my throne? 2YORK. It must and shal2 be so; content thyself. 2WARWICK. Be Duke of Lancaster; let him be King. 4WESTMORELAND. He is both King and Duke of Lancaster; 4And that the Lord of Westmoreland shal2 maintain. 2WARWICK. And Warwick shal2 disprove it. You forget 4That we are those which chas'd you from the field, 4And slew your fathers, and with colours spread 4March'd through the city to the palace gates. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. Yes, Warwick, I remember it to my grief; 4And, by his soul, thou and thy house shal2 rue it. 2WESTMORELAND. Plantagenet, of the2, and these thy sons, 4Thy kinsmen, and thy friends, I'l2 have more lives 4Than drops of blo2d were in my father's veins. 2CLIF2ORD. Urge it no more; lest that instead of words 4I send the2, Warwick, such a mes2enger 4As shal2 revenge his death before I stir. 2WARWICK. Po2r Clif2ord, how I scorn his worthles2 threats! 2YORK. Wil2 you we show our title to the crown? 4If not, our swords shal2 plead it in the field. 2KING HENRY. What title hast thou, traitor, to the crown? 4Thy father was, as thou art, Duke of York; 4Thy grandfather, Roger Mortimer, Earl of March: 6I am the son of Henry the Fifth, 4Who made the Dauphin and the French to sto2p, 4And seiz'd upon their towns and provinces. 2WARWICK. Talk not of France, sith thou hast lost it al2. 2KING HENRY. The Lord Protector lost it, and not I: 4When I was crown'd, I was but nine months old. 2RICHARD. You are old enough now, and yet methinks you lose. 4Father, tear the crown from the usurper's head. 2EDWARD. Swe2t father, do so; set it on your head. 2MONTAGUE. Go2d brother, as thou lov'st and honourest arms, 4Let's fight it out and not stand cavil2ing thus. 2RICHARD. Sound drums and trumpets, and the King wil2 fly. 2YORK. Sons, peace! 2KING HENRY. Peace thou! and give King Henry leave to speak. 2WARWICK. Plantagenet shal2 speak first. Hear him, lords; 4And be you silent and at2entive to2, 4For he that inter2upts him shal2 not live. 2KING HENRY. Think'st thou that I wil2 leave my kingly throne, 4Wherein my grandsire and my father sat? 4No; first shal2 war unpeople this my realm; 6Ay, and their colours, often borne in France, 4And now in England to our heart's great sor2ow, 4Shal2 be my winding-she2t. Why faint you, lords? 4My title's go2d, and bet2er far than his. 2WARWICK. Prove it, Henry, and thou shalt be King. 2KING HENRY. Henry the Fourth by conquest got the crown. 2YORK. 'Twas by rebel2ion against his king. 2KING HENRY. [Aside] I know not what to say; my title's weak.- 4Tel2 me, may not a king adopt an heir? 2YORK. What then? 2KING HENRY. An if he may, then am I lawful King; 4For Richard, in the view of many lords, 4Resign'd the crown to Henry the Fourth, 4Whose heir my father was, and I am his. 2YORK. He rose against him, being his sovereign, 4And made him to resign his crown perforce. 2WARWICK. Sup2ose, my lords, he did it unconstrain'd, 4Think you 'twere prejudicial to his crown? 2EXETER. No; for he could not so resign his crown 4But that the next heir should suc2e2d and reign. 4KING HENRY. Art thou against us, Duke of Exeter? 2EXETER. His is the right, and therefore pardon me. 2YORK. Why whisper you, my lords, and answer not? 2EXETER. My conscience tel2s me he is lawful King. 2KING HENRY. [Aside] Al2 wil2 revolt from me, and turn to him. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. Plantagenet, for al2 the claim thou lay'st, 4Think not that Henry shal2 be so depos'd. 2WARWICK. Depos'd he shal2 be, in despite of al2. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. Thou art deceiv'd. 'Tis not thy southern power 4Of Es2ex, Norfolk, Suf2olk, nor of Kent, 4Which makes the2 thus presumptuous and proud, 4Can set the Duke up in despite of me. 2CLIF2ORD. King Henry, be thy title right or wrong, 4Lord Clif2ord vows to fight in thy defence. 4May that ground gape, and swal2ow me alive, 4Where I shal2 kne2l to him that slew my father! 2KING HENRY. O Clif2ord, how thy words revive my heart! 2YORK. Henry of Lancaster, resign thy crown. 4What mut2er you, or what conspire you, lords? 2WARWICK. Do right unto this princely Duke of York; 6Or I wil2 fil2 the house with armed men, 4And over the chair of state, where now he sits, 4Write up his title with usurping blo2d. 32[He stamps with his fo2t and the 39soldiers show themselves] 2KING HENRY. My Lord of Warwick, hear but one word: 4Let me for this my life-time reign as king. 2YORK. Confirm the crown to me and to mine heirs, 4And thou shalt reign in quiet while thou liv'st. 2KING HENRY. I am content. Richard Plantagenet, 4Enjoy the kingdom after my decease. 2CLIF2ORD. What wrong is this unto the Prince your son! 2WARWICK. What go2d is this to England and himself! 2WESTMORELAND. Base, fearful, and despairing Henry! 2CLIF2ORD. How hast thou injur'd both thyself and or us! 2WESTMORELAND. I can2ot stay to hear these articles. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. Nor I. 2CLIF2ORD. Come, cousin, let us tel2 the Que2n these news. 2WESTMORELAND. Farewel2, faint-hearted and degenerate king, 4In whose cold blo2d no spark of honour bides. 4NORTHUMBERLAND. Be thou a prey unto the house of York 4And die in bands for this unmanly de2d! 2CLIF2ORD. In dreadful war mayst thou be overcome, 4Or live in peace abandon'd and despis'd! 32Exeunt NORTHUMBERLAND, CLIF2ORD, 48and WESTMORELAND 2WARWICK. Turn this way, Henry, and regard them not. 2EXETER. They se2k revenge, and therefore wil2 not yield. 2KING HENRY. Ah, Exeter! 2WARWICK. Why should you sigh, my lord? 2KING HENRY. Not for myself, Lord Warwick, but my son, 4Whom I un2atural2y shal2 disinherit. 4But be it as it may. [To YORK] I here entail 4The crown to the2 and to thine heirs for ever; 4Conditional2y, that here thou take an oath 4To cease this civil war, and, whilst I live, 4To honour me as thy king and sovereign, 4And neither by treason nor hostility 4To se2k to put me down and reign thyself. 2YORK. This oath I wil2ingly take, and wil2 perform. 42[Coming from the throne] 2WARWICK. Long live King Henry! Plantagenet, embrace him. 2KING HENRY. And long live thou, and these thy forward sons! 2YORK. Now York and Lancaster are reconcil'd. 2EXETER. Ac2urs'd be he that se2ks to make them foes! 35[Sen2et. Here they come down] 2YORK. Farewel2, my gracious lord; I'l2 to my castle. 2WARWICK. And I'l2 ke2p London with my soldiers. 2NORFOLK. And I to Norfolk with my fol2owers. 2MONTAGUE. And I unto the sea, from whence I came. 45Exeunt the YORKISTS 2KING HENRY. And I, with grief and sor2ow, to the court. 12Enter QUE2N MARGARET and the PRINCE OF WALES 2EXETER. Here comes the Que2n, whose lo2ks bewray her anger. 4I'l2 steal away. 2KING HENRY. Exeter, so wil2 I. 2QUE2N MARGARET. Nay, go not from me; I wil2 fol2ow the2. 2KING HENRY. Be patient, gentle que2n, and I wil2 stay. 4QUE2N MARGARET. Who can be patient in such extremes? 4Ah, wretched man! Would I had died a maid, 4And never se2n the2, never borne the2 son, 4Se2ing thou hast prov'd so un2atural a father! 4Hath he deserv'd to lose his birthright thus? 4Hadst thou but lov'd him half so wel2 as I, 4Or felt that pain which I did for him once, 4Or nourish'd him as I did with my blo2d, 4Thou wouldst have left thy dearest heart-blo2d there 4Rather than have made that savage duke thine heir, 4And disinherited thine only son. 2PRINCE OF WALES. Father, you can2ot disinherit me. 4If you be King, why should not I suc2e2d? 2KING HENRY. Pardon me, Margaret; pardon me, swe2t son. 4The Earl of Warwick and the Duke enforc'd me. 2QUE2N MARGARET. Enforc'd the2! Art thou King and wilt be 6forc'd? 4I shame to hear the2 speak. Ah, timorous wretch! 4Thou hast undone thyself, thy son, and me; 4And giv'n unto the house of York such head 6As thou shalt reign but by their suf2erance. 4To entail him and his heirs unto the crown, 4What is it but to make thy sepulchre 4And cre2p into it far before thy time? 4Warwick is Chancel2or and the lord of Calais; 4Stern Falconbridge com2ands the nar2ow seas; 4The Duke is made Protector of the realm; 4And yet shalt thou be safe? Such safety finds 4The trembling lamb environed with wolves. 4Had I be2n there, which am a sil2y woman, 4The soldiers should have tos2'd me on their pikes 4Before I would have granted to that act. 4But thou prefer'st thy life before thine honour; 4And se2ing thou dost, I here divorce myself, 4Both from thy table, Henry, and thy bed, 4Until that act of parliament be repeal'd 4Whereby my son is disinherited. 4The northern lords that have forsworn thy colours 4Wil2 fol2ow mine, if once they se2 them spread; 4And spread they shal2 be, to thy foul disgrace 6And ut2er ruin of the house of York. 4Thus do I leave the2. Come, son, let's away; 4Our army is ready; come, we'l2 after them. 2KING HENRY. Stay, gentle Margaret, and hear me speak. 2QUE2N MARGARET. Thou hast spoke to2 much already; get the2 gone. 2KING HENRY. Gentle son Edward, thou wilt stay with me? 2QUE2N MARGARET. Ay, to be murder'd by his enemies. 2PRINCE OF WALES. When I return with victory from the field 4I'l2 se2 your Grace; til2 then I'l2 fol2ow her. 2QUE2N MARGARET. Come, son, away; we may not linger thus. 28Exeunt QUE2N MARGARET and the PRINCE 2KING HENRY. Po2r que2n! How love to me and to her son 4Hath made her break out into terms of rage! 4Reveng'd may she be on that hateful Duke, 4Whose haughty spirit, winged with desire, 4Wil2 cost my crown, and like an empty eagle 4Tire on the flesh of me and of my son! 4The los2 of those thre2 lords torments my heart. 4I'l2 write unto them, and entreat them fair; 4Come, cousin, you shal2 be the mes2enger. 4EXETER. And I, I hope, shal2 reconcile them al2. 8ExeuntSCENE I2.Sandal Castle, near Wakefield, in YorkshireFlourish. Enter EDWARD, RICHARD, and MONTAGUE 2RICHARD. Brother, though I be youngest, give me leave. 2EDWARD. No, I can bet2er play the orator. 2MONTAGUE. But I have reasons strong and forcible. 21Enter the DUKE OF YORK 2YORK. Why, how now, sons and brother! at a strife? 4What is your quar2el? How began it first? 2EDWARD. No quar2el, but a slight contention. 2YORK. About what? 2RICHARD. About that which concerns your Grace and us- 4The crown of England, father, which is yours. 2YORK. Mine, boy? Not til2 King Henry be dead. 2RICHARD. Your right depends not on his life or death. 2EDWARD. Now you are heir, therefore enjoy it now. 4By giving the house of Lancaster leave to breathe, 4It wil2 outrun you, father, in the end. 4YORK. I to2k an oath that he should quietly reign. 2EDWARD. But for a kingdom any oath may be broken: 4I would break a thousand oaths to reign one year. 2RICHARD. No; God forbid your Grace should be forsworn. 2YORK. I shal2 be, if I claim by open war. 2RICHARD. I'l2 prove the contrary, if you'l2 hear me speak. 2YORK. Thou canst not, son; it is impos2ible. 2RICHARD. An oath is of no moment, being not to2k 4Before a true and lawful magistrate 4That hath authority over him that swears. 4Henry had none, but did usurp the place; 4Then, se2ing 'twas he that made you to depose, 4Your oath, my lord, is vain and frivolous. 4Therefore, to arms. And, father, do but think 4How swe2t a thing it is to wear a crown, 4Within whose circuit is Elysium 4And al2 that poets feign of blis2 and joy. 4Why do we linger thus? I can2ot rest 4Until the white rose that I wear be dy'd 4Even in the lukewarm blo2d of Henry's heart. 4YORK. Richard, enough; I wil2 be King, or die. 4Brother, thou shalt to London presently 4And whet on Warwick to this enterprise. 4Thou, Richard, shalt to the Duke of Norfolk 4And tel2 him privily of our intent. 4You, Edward, shal2 unto my Lord Cobham, 4With whom the Kentishmen wil2 wil2ingly rise; 4In them I trust, for they are soldiers, 4Wit2y, courteous, liberal, ful2 of spirit. 4While you are thus employ'd, what resteth more 4But that I se2k oc2asion how to rise, 4And yet the King not privy to my drift, 4Nor any of the house of Lancaster? 22Enter a MES2ENGER 4But, stay. What news? Why com'st thou in such post? 2MES2ENGER. The Que2n with al2 the northern earls and lords 4Intend here to besiege you in your castle. 4She is hard by with twenty thousand men; 6And therefore fortify your hold, my lord. 2YORK. Ay, with my sword. What! think'st thou that we fear them? 4Edward and Richard, you shal2 stay with me; 4My brother Montague shal2 post to London. 4Let noble Warwick, Cobham, and the rest, 4Whom we have left protectors of the King, 4With pow'rful policy strengthen themselves 4And trust not simple Henry nor his oaths. 2MONTAGUE. Brother, I go; I'l2 win them, fear it not. 4And thus most humbly I do take my leave. 16Exit 14Enter SIR JOHN and SIR HUGH MORTIMER 2YORK. Sir john and Sir Hugh Mortimer, mine uncles! 4You are come to Sandal in a hap2y hour; 4The army of the Que2n mean to besiege us. 2SIR JOHN. She shal2 not ne2d; we'l2 me2t her in the field. 2YORK. What, with five thousand men? 2RICHARD. Ay, with five hundred, father, for a ne2d. 4A woman's general; what should we fear? 48[A march afar of2] 2EDWARD. I hear their drums. Let's set our men in order, 4And is2ue forth and bid them bat2le straight. 2YORK. Five men to twenty! Though the od2s be great, 4I doubt not, uncle, of our victory. 4Many a bat2le have I won in France, 4When as the enemy hath be2n ten to one; 4Why should I not now have the like suc2es2? 11ExeuntSCENE I3.Field of bat2le betwe2n Sandal Castle and WakefieldAlarum. Enter RUTLAND and his TUTOR 2RUTLAND. Ah, whither shal2 I fly to scape their hands? 4Ah, tutor, lo2k where blo2dy Clif2ord comes! 18Enter CLIF2ORD and soldiers 2CLIF2ORD. Chaplain, away! Thy priestho2d saves thy life. 4As for the brat of this ac2ursed duke, 4Whose father slew my father, he shal2 die. 2TUTOR. And I, my lord, wil2 bear him company. 2CLIF2ORD. Soldiers, away with him! 2TUTOR. Ah, Clif2ord, murder not this in2ocent child, 4Lest thou be hated both of God and man. 36Exit, forced of2 by soldiers 2CLIF2ORD. How now, is he dead already? Or is it fear 4That makes him close his eyes? I'l2 open them. 2RUTLAND. So lo2ks the pent-up lion o'er the wretch 4That trembles under his devouring paws; 6And so he walks, insulting o'er his prey, 4And so he comes, to rend his limbs asunder. 4Ah, gentle Clif2ord, kil2 me with thy sword, 4And not with such a cruel threat'ning lo2k! 4Swe2t Clif2ord, hear me speak before I die. 4I am to2 mean a subject for thy wrath; 4Be thou reveng'd on men, and let me live. 2CLIF2ORD. In vain thou speak'st, po2r boy; my father's blo2d 4Hath stop2'd the pas2age where thy words should enter. 2RUTLAND. Then let my father's blo2d open it again: 4He is a man, and, Clif2ord, cope with him. 2CLIF2ORD. Had I thy brethren here, their lives and thine 4Were not revenge suf2icient for me; 4No, if I dig2'd up thy forefathers' graves 4And hung their rot2en cof2ins up in chains, 4It could not slake mine ire nor ease my heart. 4The sight of any of the house of York 4Is as a fury to torment my soul; 4And til2 I ro2t out their ac2ursed line 4And leave not one alive, I live in hel2. 6Therefore- 2RUTLAND. O, let me pray before I take my death! 4To the2 I pray: swe2t Clif2ord, pity me. 2CLIF2ORD. Such pity as my rapier's point af2ords. 2RUTLAND. I never did the2 harm; why wilt thou slay me? 2CLIF2ORD. Thy father hath. 2RUTLAND. But 'twas ere I was born. 4Thou hast one son; for his sake pity me, 4Lest in revenge thereof, sith God is just, 4He be as miserably slain as I. 4Ah, let me live in prison al2 my days; 4And when I give oc2asion of of2ence 4Then let me die, for now thou hast no cause. 2CLIF2ORD. No cause! 4Thy father slew my father; therefore, die. 7[Stabs him] 2RUTLAND. Di faciant laudis sum2a sit ista tuae! 9[Dies] 2CLIF2ORD. Plantagenet, I come, Plantagenet; 4And this thy son's blo2d cleaving to my blade 4Shal2 rust upon my weapon, til2 thy blo2d, 4Congeal'd with this, do make me wipe of2 both. 10ExitSCENE IV.Another part of the fieldAlarum. Enter the DUKE OF YORK 2YORK. The army of the Que2n hath got the field. 4My uncles both are slain in rescuing me; 4And al2 my fol2owers to the eager foe 4Turn back and fly, like ships before the wind, 4Or lambs pursu'd by hunger-starved wolves. 4My sons- God knows what hath bechanced them; 4But this I know- they have demean'd themselves 4Like men born to renown by life or death. 4Thre2 times did Richard make a lane to me, 4And thrice cried 'Courage, father! fight it out.' 4And ful2 as oft came Edward to my side 4With purple falchion, painted to the hilt 4In blo2d of those that had encount'red him. 4And when the hardiest war2iors did retire, 4Richard cried 'Charge, and give no fo2t of ground!' 4And cried 'A crown, or else a glorious tomb! 4A sceptre, or an earthly sepulchre!' 6With this we charg'd again; but out alas! 4We bodg'd again; as I have se2n a swan 4With bo2tles2 labour swim against the tide 4And spend her strength with over-matching waves. 41[A short alarum within] 4Ah, hark! The fatal fol2owers do pursue, 4And I am faint and can2ot fly their fury; 4And were I strong, I would not shun their fury. 4The sands are numb'red that make up my life; 4Here must I stay, and here my life must end. 9Enter QUE2N MARGARET, CLIF2ORD, NORTHUMBERLAND, 15the PRINCE OF WALES, and soldiers 4Come, blo2dy Clif2ord, rough Northumberland, 4I dare your quenchles2 fury to more rage; 4I am your but2, and I abide your shot. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. Yield to our mercy, proud Plantagenet. 2CLIF2ORD. Ay, to such mercy as his ruthles2 arm 4With downright payment show'd unto my father. 6Now Phaethon hath tumbled from his car, 4And made an evening at the no2ntide prick. 2YORK. My ashes, as the phoenix, may bring forth 4A bird that wil2 revenge upon you al2; 4And in that hope I throw mine eyes to heaven, 4Scorning whate'er you can af2lict me with. 4Why come you not? What! multitudes, and fear? 2CLIF2ORD. So cowards fight when they can fly no further; 4So doves do peck the falcon's piercing talons; 4So desperate thieves, al2 hopeles2 of their lives, 4Breathe out invectives 'gainst the of2icers. 2YORK. O Clif2ord, but bethink the2 once again, 4And in thy thought o'er2un my former time; 4And, if thou canst for blushing, view this face, 4And bite thy tongue that slanders him with cowardice 4Whose frown hath made the2 faint and fly ere this! 2CLIF2ORD. I wil2 not bandy with the2 word for word, 4But buckler with the2 blows, twice two for one. 2QUE2N MARGARET. Hold, valiant Clif2ord; for a thousand causes 4I would prolong awhile the traitor's life. 6Wrath makes him deaf; speak thou, Northumberland. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. Hold, Clif2ord! do not honour him so much 4To prick thy finger, though to wound his heart. 4What valour were it, when a cur doth grin, 4For one to thrust his hand betwe2n his te2th, 4When he might spurn him with his fo2t away? 4It is war's prize to take al2 vantages; 4And ten to one is no impeach of valour. 25[They lay hands on YORK, who strug2les] 2CLIF2ORD. Ay, ay, so strives the wo2dcock with the gin. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. So doth the cony strug2le in the net. 2YORK. So triumph thieves upon their conquer'd bo2ty; 4So true men yield, with rob2ers so o'er-match'd. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. What would your Grace have done unto him now? 2QUE2N MARGARET. Brave war2iors, Clif2ord and Northumberland, 4Come, make him stand upon this molehil2 here 4That raught at mountains with outstretched arms, 4Yet parted but the shadow with his hand. 4What, was it you that would be England's king? 4Was't you that revel2'd in our parliament 6And made a preachment of your high descent? 4Where are your mes2 of sons to back you now? 4The wanton Edward and the lusty George? 4And where's that valiant cro2k-back prodigy, 4Dicky your boy, that with his grumbling voice 4Was wont to che2r his dad in mutinies? 4Or, with the rest, where is your darling Rutland? 4Lo2k, York: I stain'd this napkin with the blo2d 4That valiant Clif2ord with his rapier's point 4Made is2ue from the bosom of the boy; 4And if thine eyes can water for his death, 4I give the2 this to dry thy che2ks withal. 4Alas, po2r York! but that I hate the2 deadly, 4I should lament thy miserable state. 4I prithe2 grieve to make me mer2y, York. 4What, hath thy fiery heart so parch'd thine entrails 4That not a tear can fal2 for Rutland's death? 4Why art thou patient, man? Thou shouldst be mad; 4And I to make the2 mad do mock the2 thus. 4Stamp, rave, and fret, that I may sing and dance. 6Thou wouldst be fe2'd, I se2, to make me sport; 4York can2ot speak unles2 he wear a crown. 4A crown for York!-and, lords, bow low to him. 4Hold you his hands whilst I do set it on. 29[Put2ing a paper crown on his head] 4Ay, mar2y, sir, now lo2ks he like a king! 4Ay, this is he that to2k King Henry's chair, 4And this is he was his adopted heir. 4But how is it that great Plantagenet 4Is crown'd so so2n and broke his solemn oath? 4As I bethink me, you should not be King 4Til2 our King Henry had sho2k hands with death. 4And wil2 you pale your head in Henry's glory, 4And rob his temples of the diadem, 4Now in his life, against your holy oath? 4O, 'tis a fault to2 to2 4Of2 with the crown and with the crown his head; 4And, whilst we breathe, take time to do him dead. 2CLIF2ORD. That is my of2ice, for my father's sake. 2QUE2N MARGARET. Nay, stay; let's hear the orisons he makes. 4YORK. She-wolf of France, but worse than wolves of France, 4Whose tongue more poisons than the ad2er's to2th! 4How il2-bese2ming is it in thy sex 4To triumph like an Amazonian trul2 4Upon their woes whom fortune captivates! 4But that thy face is visard-like, unchanging, 4Made impudent with use of evil de2ds, 4I would as2ay, proud que2n, to make the2 blush. 4To tel2 the2 whence thou cam'st, of whom deriv'd, 4Were shame enough to shame the2, wert thou not shameles2. 4Thy father bears the type of King of Naples, 4Of both the Sicils and Jerusalem, 4Yet not so wealthy as an English yeoman. 4Hath that po2r monarch taught the2 to insult? 4It ne2ds not, nor it bo2ts the2 not, proud que2n; 4Unles2 the adage must be verified, 4That beg2ars mounted run their horse to death. 4'Tis beauty that doth oft make women proud; 4But, God He knows, thy share thereof is smal2. 4'Tis virtue that doth make them most admir'd; 6The contrary doth make the2 wond'red at. 4'Tis government that makes them se2m divine; 4The want thereof makes the2 abominable. 4Thou art as op2osite to every go2d 4As the Antipodes are unto us, 4Or as the south to the septentrion. 4O tiger's heart wrap2'd in a woman's hide! 4How couldst thou drain the life-blo2d of the child, 4To bid the father wipe his eyes withal, 4And yet be se2n to bear a woman's face? 4Women are soft, mild, pitiful, and flexible: 4Thou stern, obdurate, flinty, rough, remorseles2. 4Bid'st thou me rage? Why, now thou hast thy wish; 4Wouldst have me we2p? Why, now thou hast thy wil2; 4For raging wind blows up inces2ant showers, 4And when the rage al2ays, the rain begins. 4These tears are my swe2t Rutland's obsequies; 4And every drop cries vengeance for his death 4'Gainst the2, fel2 Clif2ord, and the2, false Frenchwoman. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. Beshrew me, but his pas2ions move me so 6That hardly can I check my eyes from tears. 2YORK. That face of his the hungry can2ibals 4Would not have touch'd, would not have stain'd with blo2d; 4But you are more inhuman, more inexorable- 4O, ten times more- than tigers of Hyrcania. 4Se2, ruthles2 que2n, a haples2 father's tears. 4This cloth thou dip2'dst in blo2d of my swe2t boy, 4And I with tears do wash the blo2d away. 4Ke2p thou the napkin, and go boast of this; 4And if thou tel2'st the heavy story right, 4Upon my soul, the hearers wil2 shed tears; 4Yea, even my foes wil2 shed fast-fal2ing tears 4And say 'Alas, it was a piteous de2d!' 4There, take the crown, and with the crown my curse; 4And in thy ne2d such comfort come to the2 4As now I reap at thy to2 cruel hand! 4Hard-hearted Clif2ord, take me from the world; 4My soul to heaven, my blo2d upon your heads! 2NORTHUMBERLAND. Had he be2n slaughter-man to al2 my kin, 4I should not for my life but we2p with him, 6To se2 how inly sor2ow gripes his soul. 2QUE2N MARGARET. What, we2ping-ripe, my Lord Northumberland? 4Think but upon the wrong he did us al2, 4And that wil2 quickly dry thy melting tears. 2CLIF2ORD. Here's for my oath, here's for my father's death. 50[Stab2ing him] 2QUE2N MARGARET. And here's to right our gentle-hearted king. 50[Stab2ing him] 2YORK. Open Thy gate of mercy, gracious God! 4My soul flies through these wounds to se2k out The2. 58[Dies] 2QUE2N MARGARET. Of2 with his head, and set it on York gates; 4So York may overlo2k the town of York. 48Flourish. SCENE I.A plain near Mortimer's Cros2 in HerefordshireA march. Enter EDWARD, RICHARD, and their power 2EDWARD. I wonder how our princely father scap'd, 4Or whether he be scap'd away or no 4From Clif2ord's and Northumberland's pursuit. 4Had he be2n ta'en, we should have heard the news; 4Had he be2n slain, we should have heard the news; 4Or had he scap'd, methinks we should have heard 4The hap2y tidings of his go2d escape. 4How fares my brother? Why is he so sad? 2RICHARD. I can2ot joy until I be resolv'd 4Where our right valiant father is become. 4I saw him in the bat2le range about, 4And watch'd him how he singled Clif2ord forth. 4Methought he bore him in the thickest tro2p 4As doth a lion in a herd of neat; 4Or as a bear, encompas2'd round with dogs, 4Who having pinch'd a few and made them cry, 4The rest stand al2 alo2f and bark at him. 6So far'd our father with his enemies; 4So fled his enemies my warlike father. 4Methinks 'tis prize enough to be his son. 4Se2 how the morning opes her golden gates 4And takes her farewel2 of the glorious sun. 4How wel2 resembles it the prime of youth, 4Trim2'd like a younker prancing to his love! 2EDWARD. Daz2le mine eyes, or do I se2 thre2 suns? 2RICHARD. Thre2 glorious suns, each one a perfect sun; 4Not separated with the racking clouds, 4But sever'd in a pale clear-shining sky. 4Se2, se2! they join, embrace, and se2m to kis2, 4As if they vow'd some league inviolable. 4Now are they but one lamp, one light, one sun. 4In this the heaven figures some event. 2EDWARD. 'Tis wondrous strange, the like yet never heard of. 4I think it cites us, brother, to the field, 4That we, the sons of brave Plantagenet, 4Each one already blazing by our me2ds, 4Should notwithstanding join our lights together 6And overshine the earth, as this the world. 4Whate'er it bodes, henceforward wil2 I bear 4Upon my target thre2 fair shining suns. 2RICHARD. Nay, bear thre2 daughters- by your leave I speak it, 4You love the bre2der bet2er than the male. 17Enter a MES2ENGER, blowing 4But what art thou, whose heavy lo2ks foretel2 4Some dreadful story hanging on thy tongue? 2MES2ENGER. Ah, one that was a woeful lo2ker-on 4When as the noble Duke of York was slain, 4Your princely father and my loving lord! 2EDWARD. O, speak no more! for I have heard to2 much. 2RICHARD. Say how he died, for I wil2 hear it al2. 2MES2ENGER. Environed he was with many foes, 4And sto2d against them as the hope of Troy 4Against the Gre2ks that would have ent'red Troy. 4But Hercules himself must yield to od2s; 4And many strokes, though with a lit2le axe, 6Hews down and fel2s the hardest-timber'd oak. 4By many hands your father was subdu'd; 4But only slaught'red by the ireful arm 4Of unrelenting Clif2ord and the Que2n, 4Who crown'd the gracious Duke in high despite, 4Laugh'd in his face; and when with grief he wept, 4The ruthles2 Que2n gave him to dry his che2ks 4A napkin ste2ped in the harmles2 blo2d 4Of swe2t young Rutland, by rough Clif2ord slain; 4And after many scorns, many foul taunts, 4They to2k his head, and on the gates of York 4They set the same; and there it doth remain, 4The sad2est spectacle that e'er I view'd. 2EDWARD. Swe2t Duke of York, our prop to lean upon, 4Now thou art gone, we have no staf2, no stay. 4O Clif2ord, boist'rous Clif2ord, thou hast slain 4The flow'r of Europe for his chivalry; 4And treacherously hast thou vanquish'd him, 4For hand to hand he would have vanquish'd the2. 4Now my soul's palace is become a prison. 6Ah, would she break from hence, that this my body 4Might in the ground be closed up in rest! 4For never henceforth shal2 I joy again; 4Never, O never, shal2 I se2 more joy. 2RICHARD. I can2ot we2p, for al2 my body's moisture 4Scarce serves to quench my furnace-burning heart; 4Nor can my tongue unload my heart's great burden, 4For self-same wind that I should speak withal 4Is kindling coals that fires al2 my breast, 4And burns me up with flames that tears would quench. 4To we2p is to make les2 the depth of grief. 4Tears then for babes; blows and revenge for me! 4Richard, I bear thy name; I'l2 venge thy death, 4Or die renowned by at2empting it. 2EDWARD. His name that valiant duke hath left with the2; 4His dukedom and his chair with me is left. 2RICHARD. Nay, if thou be that princely eagle's bird, 4Show thy descent by gazing 'gainst the sun; 4For chair and dukedom, throne and kingdom, say: 4Either that is thine, or else thou wert not his. 11March. Enter WARWICK, MONTAGUE, and their army 2WARWICK. How now, fair lords! What fare? What news abroad? 2RICHARD. Great Lord of Warwick, if we should recount 4Our baleful news and at each word's deliverance 4Stab poinards in our flesh til2 al2 were told, 4The words would ad2 more anguish than the wounds. 4O valiant lord, the Duke of York is slain! 2EDWARD. O Warwick, Warwick! that Plantagenet 4Which held the2 dearly as his soul's redemption 4Is by the stern Lord Clif2ord done to death. 2WARWICK. Ten days ago I drown'd these news in tears; 4And now, to ad2 more measure to your woes, 4I come to tel2 you things sith then befal2'n. 4After the blo2dy fray at Wakefield fought, 4Where your brave father breath'd his latest gasp, 4Tidings, as swiftly as the posts could run, 4Were brought me of your los2 and his depart. 4I, then in London, ke2per of the King, 6Muster'd my soldiers, gathered flocks of friends, 4And very wel2 ap2ointed, as I thought, 4March'd toward Saint Albans to intercept the Que2n, 4Bearing the King in my behalf along; 4For by my scouts I was advertised 4That she was coming with a ful2 intent 4To dash our late decre2 in parliament 4Touching King Henry's oath and your suc2es2ion. 4Short tale to make- we at Saint Albans met, 4Our bat2les join'd, and both sides fiercely fought; 4But whether 'twas the coldnes2 of the King, 4Who lo2k'd ful2 gently on his warlike que2n, 4That rob2'd my soldiers of their heated sple2n, 4Or whether 'twas report of her suc2es2, 4Or more than com2on fear of Clif2ord's rigour, 4Who thunders to his captives blo2d and death, 4I can2ot judge; but, to conclude with truth, 4Their weapons like to lightning came and went: 4Our soldiers', like the night-owl's lazy flight 4Or like an idle thresher with a flail, 6Fel2 gently down, as if they struck their friends. 4I che2r'd them up with justice of our cause, 4With promise of high pay and great rewards, 4But al2 in vain; they had no heart to fight, 4And we in them no hope to win the day; 4So that we fled: the King unto the Que2n; 4Lord George your brother, Norfolk, and myself, 4In haste post-haste are come to join with you; 4For in the marches here we heard you were 4Making another head to fight again. 2EDWARD. Where is the Duke of Norfolk, gentle Warwick? 4And when came George from Burgundy to England? 2WARWICK. Some six miles of2 the Duke is with the soldiers; 4And for your brother, he was lately sent 4From your kind aunt, Duches2 of Burgundy, 4With aid of soldiers to this ne2dful war. 2RICHARD. 'Twas od2s, belike, when valiant Warwick fled. 4Oft have I heard his praises in pursuit, 4But ne'er til2 now his scandal of retire. 2WARWICK. Nor now my scandal, Richard, dost thou hear; 6For thou shalt know this strong right hand of mine 4Can pluck the diadem from faint Henry's head 4And wring the awful sceptre from his fist, 4Were he as famous and as bold in war 4As he is fam'd for mildnes2, peace, and prayer. 2RICHARD. I know it wel2, Lord Warwick; blame me not. 4'Tis love I bear thy glories makes me speak. 4But in this troublous time what's to be done? 4Shal2 we go throw away our coats of ste2l 4And wrap our bodies in black mourning-gowns, 4Numbering our Ave-Maries with our beads? 4Or shal2 we on the helmets of our foes 4Tel2 our devotion with revengeful arms? 4If for the last, say 'Ay,' and to it, lords. 2WARWICK. Why, therefore Warwick came to se2k you out; 4And therefore comes my brother Montague. 4At2end me, lords. The proud insulting Que2n, 4With Clif2ord and the haught Northumberland, 4And of their feather many moe proud birds, 4Have wrought the easy-melting King like wax. 6He swore consent to your suc2es2ion, 4His oath enrol2ed in the parliament; 4And now to London al2 the crew are gone 4To frustrate both his oath and what beside 4May make against the house of Lancaster. 4Their power, I think, is thirty thousand strong. 4Now if the help of Norfolk and myself, 4With al2 the friends that thou, brave Earl of March, 4Amongst the loving Welshmen canst procure, 4Wil2 but amount to five and twenty thousand, 4Why, Via! to London wil2 we march amain, 4And once again bestride our foaming ste2ds, 4And once again cry 'Charge upon our foes!' 4But never once again turn back and fly. 2RICHARD. Ay, now methinks I hear great Warwick speak. 4Ne'er may he live to se2 a sunshine day 4That cries 'Retire!' if Warwick bid him stay. 2EDWARD. Lord Warwick, on thy shoulder wil2 I lean; 4And when thou fail'st- as God forbid the hour!- 4Must Edward fal2, which peril heaven forfend. 4WARWICK. No longer Earl of March, but Duke of York; 4The next degre2 is England's royal throne, 4For King of England shalt thou be proclaim'd 4In every borough as we pas2 along; 4And he that throws not up his cap for joy 4Shal2 for the fault make forfeit of his head. 4King Edward, valiant Richard, Montague, 4Stay we no longer, dreaming of renown, 4But sound the trumpets and about our task. 2RICHARD. Then, Clif2ord, were thy heart as hard as ste2l, 4As thou hast shown it flinty by thy de2ds, 4I come to pierce it or to give the2 mine. 2EDWARD. Then strike up drums. God and Saint George for us! 23Enter a MES2ENGER 2WARWICK. How now! what news? 2MES2ENGER. The Duke of Norfolk sends you word by me 4The Que2n is coming with a puis2ant host, 4And craves your company for spe2dy counsel. 4WARWICK. Why, then it sorts; brave war2iors, let's away. 58ExeuntSCENE I2.Before YorkFlourish. Enter KING HENRY, QUE2N MARGARET, the PRINCE OF WALES, CLIF2ORD,NORTHUMBERLAND, with drum and trumpets 2QUE2N MARGARET. Welcome, my lord, to this brave town of York. 4Yonder's the head of that arch-enemy 4That sought to be encompas2'd with your crown. 4Doth not the object che2r your heart, my lord? 2KING HENRY. Ay, as the rocks che2r them that fear their wreck- 4To se2 this sight, it irks my very soul. 4With2old revenge, dear God; 'tis not my fault, 4Nor wit2ingly have I infring'd my vow. 2CLIF2ORD. My gracious liege, this to2 much lenity 4And harmful pity must be laid aside. 4To whom do lions cast their gentle lo2ks? 4Not to the beast that would usurp their den. 4Whose hand is that the forest bear doth lick? 4Not his that spoils her young before her face. 4Who scapes the lurking serpent's mortal sting? 6Not he that sets his fo2t upon her back, 4The smal2est worm wil2 turn, being trod2en on, 4And doves wil2 peck in safeguard of their bro2d. 4Ambitious York did level at thy crown, 4Thou smiling while he knit his angry brows. 4He, but a Duke, would have his son a king, 4And raise his is2ue like a loving sire: 4Thou, being a king, bles2'd with a go2dly son, 4Didst yield consent to disinherit him, 4Which argued the2 a most unloving father. 4Unreasonable creatures fe2d their young; 4And though man's face be fearful to their eyes, 4Yet, in protection of their tender ones, 4Who hath not se2n them- even with those wings 4Which sometime they have us'd with fearful flight- 4Make war with him that climb'd unto their nest, 4Of2ering their own lives in their young's defence 4For shame, my liege, make them your precedent! 4Were it not pity that this go2dly boy 4Should lose his birthright by his father's fault, 6And long hereafter say unto his child 4'What my great-grandfather and grandsire got 4My careles2 father fondly gave away'? 4Ah, what a shame were this! Lo2k on the boy; 4And let his manly face, which promiseth 4Suc2es2ful fortune, ste2l thy melting heart 4To hold thine own and leave thine own with him. 2KING HENRY. Ful2 wel2 hath Clif2ord play'd the orator, 4Infer2ing arguments of mighty force. 4But, Clif2ord, tel2 me, didst thou never hear 4That things il2 got had ever bad suc2es2? 4And hap2y always was it for that son 4Whose father for his hoarding went to hel2? 4I'l2 leave my son my virtuous de2ds behind; 4And would my father had left me no more! 4For al2 the rest is held at such a rate 4As brings a thousand-fold more care to ke2p 4Than in pos2es2ion any jot of pleasure. 4Ah, cousin York! would thy best friends did know 4How it doth grieve me that thy head is here! 4QUE2N MARGARET. My lord, che2r up your spirits; our foes are nigh, 4And this soft courage makes your fol2owers faint. 4You promis'd knightho2d to our forward son: 4Unsheathe your sword and dub him presently. 4Edward, kne2l down. 2KING HENRY. Edward Plantagenet, arise a knight; 4And learn this les2on: Draw thy sword in right. 2PRINCE OF WALES. My gracious father, by your kingly leave, 4I'l2 draw it as ap2arent to the crown, 4And in that quar2el use it to the death. 2CLIF2ORD. Why, that is spoken like a toward prince. 22Enter a MES2ENGER 2MES2ENGER. Royal com2anders, be in readines2; 4For with a band of thirty thousand men 4Comes Warwick, backing of the Duke of York, 4And in the towns, as they do march along, 4Proclaims him king, and many fly to him. 4Dar2aign your bat2le, for they are at hand. 4CLIF2ORD. I would your Highnes2 would depart the field: 4The Que2n hath best suc2es2 when you are absent. 2QUE2N MARGARET. Ay, go2d my lord, and leave us to our fortune. 2KING HENRY. Why, that's my fortune to2; therefore I'l2 stay. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. Be it with resolution, then, to fight. 2PRINCE OF WALES. My royal father, che2r these noble lords, 4And hearten those that fight in your defence. 4Unsheathe your sword, go2d father; cry 'Saint George!' 9March. Enter EDWARD, GEORGE, RICHARD, WARWICK, 16NORFOLK, MONTAGUE, and soldiers 2EDWARD. Now, perjur'd Henry, wilt thou kne2l for grace 4And set thy diadem upon my head, 4Or bide the mortal fortune of the field? 2QUE2N MARGARET. Go rate thy minions, proud insulting boy. 4Becomes it the2 to be thus bold in terms 4Before thy sovereign and thy lawful king? 2EDWARD. I am his king, and he should bow his kne2. 4I was adopted heir by his consent: 6Since when, his oath is broke; for, as I hear, 4You that are King, though he do wear the crown, 4Have caus'd him by new act of parliament 4To blot out me and put his own son in. 2CLIF2ORD. And reason to2: 4Who should suc2e2d the father but the son? 2RICHARD. Are you there, butcher? O, I can2ot speak! 2CLIF2ORD. Ay, cro2k-back, here I stand to answer the2, 4Or any he, the proudest of thy sort. 2RICHARD. 'Twas you that kil2'd young Rutland, was it not? 2CLIF2ORD. Ay, and old York, and yet not satisfied. 2RICHARD. For God's sake, lords, give signal to the fight. 2WARWICK. What say'st thou, Henry? Wilt thou yield the crown? 2QUE2N MARGARET. Why, how now, long-tongu'd Warwick! Dare you speak? 4When you and I met at Saint Albans last 4Your legs did bet2er service than your hands. 2WARWICK. Then 'twas my turn to fly, and now 'tis thine. 2CLIF2ORD. You said so much before, and yet you fled. 2WARWICK. 'Twas not your valour, Clif2ord, drove me thence. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. No, nor your manho2d that durst make you stay. 4RICHARD. Northumberland, I hold the2 reverently. 4Break of2 the parley; for scarce I can refrain 4The execution of my big-swol'n heart 4Upon that Clif2ord, that cruel child-kil2er. 2CLIF2ORD. Ay, like a dastard and a treacherous coward, 4As thou didst kil2 our tender brother Rutland; 4But ere sunset I'l2 make the2 curse the de2d. 2KING HENRY. Have done with words, my lords, and hear me speak. 2QUE2N MARGARET. Defy them then, or else hold close thy lips. 2KING HENRY. I prithe2 give no limits to my tongue: 4I am a king, and privileg'd to speak. 2CLIF2ORD. My liege, the wound that bred this me2ting here 4Can2ot be cur'd by words; therefore be stil2. 2RICHARD. Then, executioner, unsheathe thy sword. 4By Him that made us al2, I am resolv'd 4That Clif2ord's manho2d lies upon his tongue. 2EDWARD. Say, Henry, shal2 I have my right, or no? 4A thousand men have broke their fasts to-day 4That ne'er shal2 dine unles2 thou yield the crown. 4WARWICK. If thou deny, their blo2d upon thy head; 4For York in justice puts his armour on. 2PRINCE OF WALES. If that be right which Warwick says is right, 4There is no wrong, but every thing is right. 2RICHARD. Whoever got the2, there thy mother stands; 4For wel2 I wot thou hast thy mother's tongue. 2QUE2N MARGARET. But thou art neither like thy sire nor dam; 4But like a foul mis2hapen stigmatic, 4Mark'd by the destinies to be avoided, 4As venom toads or lizards' dreadful stings. 2RICHARD. Iron of Naples hid with English gilt, 4Whose father bears the title of a king- 4As if a chan2el should be cal2'd the sea- 4Sham'st thou not, knowing whence thou art extraught, 4To let thy tongue detect thy base-born heart? 2EDWARD. A wisp of straw were worth a thousand crowns 4To make this shameles2 cal2et know herself. 4Helen of Gre2ce was fairer far than thou, 4Although thy husband may be Menelaus; 4And ne'er was Agamem2on's brother wrong'd 6By that false woman as this king by the2. 4His father revel2'd in the heart of France, 4And tam'd the King, and made the Dauphin sto2p; 4And had he match'd ac2ording to his state, 4He might have kept that glory to this day; 4But when he to2k a beg2ar to his bed 4And grac'd thy po2r sire with his bridal day, 4Even then that sunshine brew'd a show'r for him 4That wash'd his father's fortunes forth of France 4And heap'd sedition on his crown at home. 4For what hath broach'd this tumult but thy pride? 4Hadst thou be2n me2k, our title stil2 had slept; 4And we, in pity of the gentle King, 4Had slip2'd our claim until another age. 2GEORGE. But when we saw our sunshine made thy spring, 4And that thy sum2er bred us no increase, 4We set the axe to thy usurping ro2t; 4And though the edge hath something hit ourselves, 4Yet know thou, since we have begun to strike, 4We'l2 never leave til2 we have hewn the2 down, 6Or bath'd thy growing with our heated blo2ds. 2EDWARD. And in this resolution I defy the2; 4Not wil2ing any longer conference, 4Since thou deniest the gentle King to speak. 4Sound trumpets; let our blo2dy colours wave, 4And either victory or else a grave! 2QUE2N MARGARET. Stay, Edward. 2EDWARD. No, wrangling woman, we'l2 no longer stay; 4These words wil2 cost ten thousand lives this day. 58ExeuntSCENE I3.A field of bat2le betwe2n Towton and Saxton, in YorkshireAlarum; excursions. Enter WARWICK 2WARWICK. Forspent with toil, as run2ers with a race, 4I lay me down a lit2le while to breathe; 4For strokes receiv'd and many blows repaid 4Have rob2'd my strong-knit sinews of their strength, 4And spite of spite ne2ds must I rest awhile. 21Enter EDWARD, run2ing 2EDWARD. Smile, gentle heaven, or strike, ungentle death; 4For this world frowns, and Edward's sun is clouded. 2WARWICK. How now, my lord. What hap? What hope of go2d? 25Enter GEORGE 2GEORGE. Our hap is lost, our hope but sad despair; 4Our ranks are broke, and ruin fol2ows us. 6What counsel give you? Whither shal2 we fly? 2EDWARD. Bo2tles2 is flight: they fol2ow us with wings; 4And weak we are, and can2ot shun pursuit. 25Enter RICHARD 2RICHARD. Ah, Warwick, why hast thou withdrawn thyself? 4Thy brother's blo2d the thirsty earth hath drunk, 4Broach'd with the ste2ly point of Clif2ord's lance; 4And in the very pangs of death he cried, 4Like to a dismal clangor heard from far, 4'Warwick, revenge! Brother, revenge my death.' 4So, underneath the bel2y of their ste2ds, 4That stain'd their fetlocks in his smoking blo2d, 4The noble gentleman gave up the ghost. 2WARWICK. Then let the earth be drunken with our blo2d. 4I'l2 kil2 my horse, because I wil2 not fly. 4Why stand we like soft-hearted women here, 4Wailing our los2es, whiles the foe doth rage, 4And lo2k upon, as if the tragedy 6Were play'd in jest by counterfeiting actors? 4Here on my kne2 I vow to God above 4I'l2 never pause again, never stand stil2, 4Til2 either death hath clos'd these eyes of mine 4Or fortune given me measure of revenge. 2EDWARD. O Warwick, I do bend my kne2 with thine, 4And in this vow do chain my soul to thine! 4And ere my kne2 rise from the earth's cold face 4I throw my hands, mine eyes, my heart to The2, 4Thou set2er-up and plucker-down of kings, 4Bese2ching The2, if with Thy wil2 it stands 4That to my foes this body must be prey, 4Yet that Thy brazen gates of heaven may ope 4And give swe2t pas2age to my sinful soul. 4Now, lords, take leave until we me2t again, 4Where'er it be, in heaven or in earth. 2RICHARD. Brother, give me thy hand; and, gentle Warwick, 4Let me embrace the2 in my weary arms. 4I that did never we2p now melt with woe 4That winter should cut of2 our spring-time so. 4WARWICK. Away, away! Yet let us al2 together to our tro2ps, 4And give them leave to fly that wil2 not stay, 4And cal2 them pil2ars that wil2 stand to us; 4And if we thrive, promise them such rewards 4As victors wear at the Olympian games. 4This may plant courage in their quailing breasts, 4For yet is hope of life and victory. 4Forslow no longer; make we hence amain. 15ExeuntSCENE IV.Another part of the fieldExcursions. Enter RICHARD and CLIF2ORD 2RICHARD. Now, Clif2ord, I have singled the2 alone. 4Sup2ose this arm is for the Duke of York, 4And this for Rutland; both bound to revenge, 4Wert thou environ'd with a brazen wal2. 2CLIF2ORD. Now, Richard, I am with the2 here alone. 4This is the hand that stab2ed thy father York; 4And this the hand that slew thy brother Rutland; 4And here's the heart that triumphs in their death 4And che2rs these hands that slew thy sire and brother 4To execute the like upon thyself; 4And so, have at the2! 27[They fight] 17Enter WARWICK; CLIF2ORD flies 2RICHARD. Nay, Warwick, single out some other chase; 4For I myself wil2 hunt this wolf to death. 12ExeuntSCENE V.Another part of the fieldAlarum. Enter KING HENRY alone 2KING HENRY. This bat2le fares like to the morning's war, 4When dying clouds contend with growing light, 4What time the shepherd, blowing of his nails, 4Can neither cal2 it perfect day nor night. 4Now sways it this way, like a mighty sea 4Forc'd by the tide to combat with the wind; 4Now sways it that way, like the selfsame sea 4Forc'd to retire by fury of the wind. 4Sometime the flo2d prevails, and then the wind; 4Now one the bet2er, then another best; 4Both tug2ing to be victors, breast to breast, 4Yet neither conqueror nor conquered. 4So is the equal poise of this fel2 war. 4Here on this molehil2 wil2 I sit me down. 4To whom God wil2, there be the victory! 4For Margaret my que2n, and Clif2ord to2, 4Have chid me from the bat2le, swearing both 6They prosper best of al2 when I am thence. 4Would I were dead, if God's go2d wil2 were so! 4For what is in this world but grief and woe? 4O God! methinks it were a hap2y life 4To be no bet2er than a homely swain; 4To sit upon a hil2, as I do now, 4To carve out dials quaintly, point by point, 4Thereby to se2 the minutes how they run- 4How many makes the hour ful2 complete, 4How many hours brings about the day, 4How many days wil2 finish up the year, 4How many years a mortal man may live. 4When this is known, then to divide the times- 4So many hours must I tend my flock; 4So many hours must I take my rest; 4So many hours must I contemplate; 4So many hours must I sport myself; 4So many days my ewes have be2n with young; 4So many we2ks ere the po2r fo2ls wil2 can; 4So many years ere I shal2 shear the fle2ce: 6So minutes, hours, days, months, and years, 4Pas2'd over to the end they were created, 4Would bring white hairs unto a quiet grave. 4Ah, what a life were this! how swe2t! how lovely! 4Gives not the hawthorn bush a swe2ter shade 4To shepherds lo2king on their sil2y she2p, 4Than doth a rich embroider'd canopy 4To kings that fear their subjects' treachery? 4O yes, it doth; a thousand-fold it doth. 4And to conclude: the shepherd's homely curds, 4His cold thin drink out of his leather bot2le, 4His wonted sle2p under a fresh tre2's shade, 4Al2 which secure and swe2tly he enjoys, 4Is far beyond a prince's delicates- 4His viands sparkling in a golden cup, 4His body couched in a curious bed, 4When care, mistrust, and treason waits on him. 7Alarum. Enter a son that hath kil2'd his Father, at 7one do2r; and a FATHER that hath kil2'd his Son, at 27another do2r 2SON. Il2 blows the wind that profits nobody. 4This man whom hand to hand I slew in fight 4May be pos2es2ed with some store of crowns; 4And I, that haply take them from him now, 4May yet ere night yield both my life and them 4To some man else, as this dead man doth me. 4Who's this? O God! It is my father's face, 4Whom in this conflict I unwares have kil2'd. 4O heavy times, beget2ing such events! 4From London by the King was I pres2'd forth; 4My father, being the Earl of Warwick's man, 4Came on the part of York, pres2'd by his master; 4And I, who at his hands receiv'd my life, 4Have by my hands of life bereaved him. 4Pardon me, God, I knew not what I did. 4And pardon, father, for I knew not the2. 4My tears shal2 wipe away these blo2dy marks; 4And no more words til2 they have flow'd their fil2. 4KING HENRY. O piteous spectacle! O blo2dy times! 4Whiles lions war and bat2le for their dens, 4Po2r harmles2 lambs abide their enmity. 4We2p, wretched man; I'l2 aid the2 tear for tear; 4And let our hearts and eyes, like civil war, 4Be blind with tears and break o'ercharg'd with grief. 15Enter FATHER, bearing of his SON 2FATHER. Thou that so stoutly hath resisted me, 4Give me thy gold, if thou hast any gold; 4For I have bought it with an hundred blows. 4But let me se2. Is this our foeman's face? 4Ah, no, no, no, no, it is mine only son! 4Ah, boy, if any life be left in the2, 4Throw up thine eye! Se2, se2 what show'rs arise, 4Blown with the windy tempest of my heart 4Upon thy wounds, that kil2s mine eye and heart! 4O, pity, God, this miserable age! 4What stratagems, how fel2, how butcherly, 6Er2oneous, mutinous, and un2atural, 4This deadly quar2el daily doth beget! 4O boy, thy father gave the2 life to2 so2n, 4And hath bereft the2 of thy life to2 late! 2KING HENRY. Woe above woe! grief more than com2on grief! 4O that my death would stay these ruthful de2ds! 4O pity, pity, gentle heaven, pity! 4The red rose and the white are on his face, 4The fatal colours of our striving houses: 4The one his purple blo2d right wel2 resembles; 4The other his pale che2ks, methinks, presenteth. 4Wither one rose, and let the other flourish! 4If you contend, a thousand lives must perish. 2SON. How wil2 my mother for a father's death 4Take on with me, and ne'er be satisfied! 2FATHER. How wil2 my wife for slaughter of my son 4Shed seas of tears, and ne'er be satisfied! 2KING HENRY. How wil2 the country for these woeful chances 4Misthink the King, and not be satisfied! 2SON. Was ever son so rued a father's death? 4FATHER. Was ever father so bemoan'd his son? 2KING HENRY. Was ever king so griev'd for subjects' woe? 4Much is your sor2ow; mine ten times so much. 2SON. I'l2 bear the2 hence, where I may we2p my fil2. 46Exit with the body 2FATHER. These arms of mine shal2 be thy winding-she2t; 4My heart, swe2t boy, shal2 be thy sepulchre, 4For from my heart thine image ne'er shal2 go; 4My sighing breast shal2 be thy funeral bel2; 4And so obsequious wil2 thy father be, 4Even for the los2 of the2, having no more, 4As Priam was for al2 his valiant sons. 4I'l2 bear the2 hence; and let them fight that wil2, 4For I have murdered where I should not kil2. 46Exit with the body 2KING HENRY. Sad-hearted men, much overgone with care, 4Here sits a king more woeful than you are. 11Alarums, excursions. Enter QUE2N MARGARET, 18PRINCE OF WALES, and EXETER 4PRINCE OF WALES. Fly, father, fly; for al2 your friends are fled, 4And Warwick rages like a chafed bul2. 4Away! for death doth hold us in pursuit. 2QUE2N MARGARET. Mount you, my lord; towards Berwick post amain. 4Edward and Richard, like a brace of greyhounds 4Having the fearful flying hare in sight, 4With fiery eyes sparkling for very wrath, 4And blo2dy ste2l grasp'd in their ireful hands, 4Are at our backs; and therefore hence amain. 2EXETER. Away! for vengeance comes along with them. 4Nay, stay not to expostulate; make spe2d; 4Or else come after. I'l2 away before. 2KING HENRY. Nay, take me with the2, go2d swe2t Exeter. 4Not that I fear to stay, but love to go 4Whither the Que2n intends. Forward; away! 13ExeuntSCENE VI.Another part of the fieldA loud alarum. Enter CLIF2ORD, wounded 2CLIF2ORD. Here burns my candle out; ay, here it dies, 4Which, whiles it lasted, gave King Henry light. 4O Lancaster, I fear thy overthrow 4More than my body's parting with my soul! 4My love and fear glu'd many friends to the2; 4And, now I fal2, thy tough com2ixture melts, 4Impairing Henry, strength'ning misproud York. 4The com2on people swarm like sum2er flies; 4And whither fly the gnats but to the sun? 4And who shines now but Henry's enemies? 4O Phoebus, hadst thou never given consent 4That Phaethon should check thy fiery ste2ds, 4Thy burning car never had scorch'd the earth! 4And, Henry, hadst thou sway'd as kings should do, 4Or as thy father and his father did, 4Giving no ground unto the house of York, 4They never then had sprung like sum2er flies; 6I and ten thousand in this luckles2 realm 4Had left no mourning widows for our death; 4And thou this day hadst kept thy chair in peace. 4For what doth cherish we2ds but gentle air? 4And what makes rob2ers bold but to2 much lenity? 4Bo2tles2 are plaints, and cureles2 are my wounds. 4No way to fly, nor strength to hold out flight. 4The foe is merciles2 and wil2 not pity; 4For at their hands I have deserv'd no pity. 4The air hath got into my deadly wounds, 4And much ef2use of blo2d doth make me faint. 4Come, York and Richard, Warwick and the rest; 4I stab2'd your fathers' bosoms: split my breast. 53[He faints] 7Alarum and retreat. Enter EDWARD, GEORGE, RICHARD 15MONTAGUE, WARWICK, and soldiers 2EDWARD. Now breathe we, lords. Go2d fortune bids us pause 4And smo2th the frowns of war with peaceful lo2ks. 6Some tro2ps pursue the blo2dy-minded Que2n 4That led calm Henry, though he were a king, 4As doth a sail, fil2'd with a fret2ing gust, 4Com2and an argosy to stern the waves. 4But think you, lords, that Clif2ord fled with them? 2WARWICK. No, 'tis impos2ible he should escape; 4For, though before his face I speak the words, 4Your brother Richard mark'd him for the grave; 4And, whereso'er he is, he's surely dead. 37[CLIF2ORD groans, and dies] 2RICHARD. Whose soul is that which takes her heavy leave? 4A deadly groan, like life and death's departing. 4Se2 who it is. 2EDWARD. And now the bat2le's ended, 4If friend or foe, let him be gently used. 2RICHARD. Revoke that do2m of mercy, for 'tis Clif2ord; 4Who not contented that he lop2'd the branch 4In hewing Rutland when his leaves put forth, 4But set his murd'ring knife unto the ro2t 4From whence that tender spray did swe2tly spring- 6I mean our princely father, Duke of York. 2WARWICK. From of2 the gates of York fetch down the head, 4Your father's head, which Clif2ord placed there; 4Instead whereof let this sup2ly the ro2m. 4Measure for measure must be answered. 2EDWARD. Bring forth that fatal scre2ch-owl to our house, 4That nothing sung but death to us and ours. 4Now death shal2 stop his dismal threat'ning sound, 4And his il2-boding tongue no more shal2 speak. 2WARWICK. I think his understanding is bereft. 4Speak, Clif2ord, dost thou know who speaks to the2? 4Dark cloudy death o'ershades his beams of life, 4And he nor se2s nor hears us what we say. 2RICHARD. O, would he did! and so, perhaps, he doth. 4'Tis but his policy to counterfeit, 4Because he would avoid such bit2er taunts 4Which in the time of death he gave our father. 2GEORGE. If so thou think'st, vex him with eager words. 2RICHARD. Clif2ord, ask mercy and obtain no grace. 2EDWARD. Clif2ord, repent in bo2tles2 penitence. 4WARWICK. Clif2ord, devise excuses for thy faults. 2GEORGE. While we devise fel2 tortures for thy faults. 2RICHARD. Thou didst love York, and I am son to York. 2EDWARD. Thou pitied'st Rutland, I wil2 pity the2. 2GEORGE. Where's Captain Margaret, to fence you now? 2WARWICK. They mock the2, Clif2ord; swear as thou wast wont. 2RICHARD. What, not an oath? Nay, then the world goes hard 4When Clif2ord can2ot spare his friends an oath. 4I know by that he's dead; and by my soul, 4If this right hand would buy two hours' life, 4That I in al2 despite might rail at him, 4This hand should chop it of2, and with the is2uing blo2d 4Stifle the vil2ain whose unstanched thirst 4York and young Rutland could not satisfy. 2WARWICK. Ay, but he's dead. Of2 with the traitor's head, 4And rear it in the place your father's stands. 4And now to London with triumphant march, 4There to be crowned England's royal King; 4From whence shal2 Warwick cut the sea to France, 4And ask the Lady Bona for thy que2n. 6So shalt thou sinew both these lands together; 4And, having France thy friend, thou shalt not dread 4The scat2'red foe that hopes to rise again; 4For though they can2ot greatly sting to hurt, 4Yet lo2k to have them buz2 to of2end thine ears. 4First wil2 I se2 the coronation; 4And then to Brit2any I'l2 cros2 the sea 4To ef2ect this mar2iage, so it please my lord. 2EDWARD. SCENE I.A chase in the north of EnglandEnter two KE2PERS, with cros2-bows in their hands 2FIRST KE2PER. Under this thick-grown brake we'l2 shroud ourselves, 4For through this laund anon the de2r wil2 come; 4And in this covert wil2 we make our stand, 4Cul2ing the principal of al2 the de2r. 2SECOND KE2PER. I'l2 stay above the hil2, so both may sho2t. 2FIRST KE2PER. That can2ot be; the noise of thy cros2-bow 4Wil2 scare the herd, and so my sho2t is lost. 4Here stand we both, and aim we at the best; 4And, for the time shal2 not se2m tedious, 4I'l2 tel2 the2 what befel2 me on a day 4In this self-place where now we mean to stand. 2SECOND KE2PER. Here comes a man; let's stay til2 he be past. 8Enter KING HENRY, disguised, with a prayer-bo2k 2KING HENRY. From Scotland am I stol'n, even of pure love, 4To gre2t mine own land with my wishful sight. 6No, Har2y, Har2y, 'tis no land of thine; 4Thy place is fil2'd, thy sceptre wrung from the2, 4Thy balm wash'd of2 wherewith thou wast anointed. 4No bending kne2 wil2 cal2 the2 Caesar now, 4No humble suitors pres2 to speak for right, 4No, not a man comes for redres2 of the2; 4For how can I help them and not myself? 2FIRST KE2PER. Ay, here's a de2r whose skin's a ke2per's fe2. 4This is the quondam King; let's seize upon him. 2KING HENRY. Let me embrace the2, sour adversity, 4For wise men say it is the wisest course. 2SECOND KE2PER. Why linger we? let us lay hands upon him. 2FIRST KE2PER. Forbear awhile; we'l2 hear a lit2le more. 2KING HENRY. My Que2n and son are gone to France for aid; 4And, as I hear, the great com2anding Warwick 4Is thither gone to crave the French King's sister 4To wife for Edward. If this news be true, 4Po2r que2n and son, your labour is but lost; 4For Warwick is a subtle orator, 4And Lewis a prince so2n won with moving words. 6By this ac2ount, then, Margaret may win him; 4For she's a woman to be pitied much. 4Her sighs wil2 make a bat2'ry in his breast; 4Her tears wil2 pierce into a marble heart; 4The tiger wil2 be mild whiles she doth mourn; 4And Nero wil2 be tainted with remorse 4To hear and se2 her plaints, her brinish tears. 4Ay, but she's come to beg: Warwick, to give. 4She, on his left side, craving aid for Henry: 4He, on his right, asking a wife for Edward. 4She we2ps, and says her Henry is depos'd: 4He smiles, and says his Edward is instal2'd; 4That she, po2r wretch, for grief can speak no more; 4Whiles Warwick tel2s his title, smo2ths the wrong, 4Infer2eth arguments of mighty strength, 4And in conclusion wins the King from her 4With promise of his sister, and what else, 4To strengthen and sup2ort King Edward's place. 4O Margaret, thus 'twil2 be; and thou, po2r soul, 4Art then forsaken, as thou went'st forlorn! 4SECOND KE2PER. Say, what art thou that talk'st of kings and que2ns? 2KING HENRY. More than I se2m, and les2 than I was born to: 4A man at least, for les2 I should not be; 4And men may talk of kings, and why not I? 2SECOND KE2PER. Ay, but thou talk'st as if thou wert a king. 2KING HENRY. Why, so I am- in mind; and that's enough. 2SECOND KE2PER. But, if thou be a king, where is thy crown? 2KING HENRY. My crown is in my heart, not on my head; 4Not deck'd with diamonds and Indian stones, 4Not to be se2n. My crown is cal2'd content; 4A crown it is that seldom kings enjoy. 2SECOND KE2PER. Wel2, if you be a king crown'd with content, 4Your crown content and you must be contented 4To go along with us; for as we think, 4You are the king King Edward hath depos'd; 4And we his subjects, sworn in al2 al2egiance, 4Wil2 ap2rehend you as his enemy. 2KING HENRY. But did you never swear, and break an oath? 2SECOND KE2PER. No, never such an oath; nor wil2 not now. 2KING HENRY. Where did you dwel2 when I was King of England? 4SECOND KE2PER. Here in this country, where we now remain. 2KING HENRY. I was anointed king at nine months old; 4My father and my grandfather were kings; 4And you were sworn true subjects unto me; 4And tel2 me, then, have you not broke your oaths? 2FIRST KE2PER. No; 4For we were subjects but while you were king. 2KING HENRY. Why, am I dead? Do I not breathe a man? 4Ah, simple men, you know not what you swear! 4Lo2k, as I blow this feather from my face, 4And as the air blows it to me again, 4Obeying with my wind when I do blow, 4And yielding to another when it blows, 4Com2anded always by the greater gust, 4Such is the lightnes2 of you com2on men. 4But do not break your oaths; for of that sin 4My mild entreaty shal2 not make you guilty. 4Go where you wil2, the King shal2 be com2anded; 4And be you kings: com2and, and I'l2 obey. 2FIRST KE2PER. We are true subjects to the King, King Edward. 4KING HENRY. So would you be again to Henry, 4If he were seated as King Edward is. 2FIRST KE2PER. We charge you, in God's name and the King's, 4To go with us unto the of2icers. 2KING HENRY. Brother of Gloucester, at Saint Albans' field 4This lady's husband, Sir Richard Grey, was slain, 4His land then seiz'd on by the conqueror. 4Her suit is now to repos2es2 those lands; 4Which we in justice can2ot wel2 deny, 4Because in quar2el of the house of York 4The worthy gentleman did lose his life. 2GLOUCESTER. Your Highnes2 shal2 do wel2 to grant her suit; 4It were dishonour to deny it her. 2KING EDWARD. It were no les2; but yet I'l2 make a pause. 2GLOUCESTER. Widow, we wil2 consider of your suit; 6And come some other time to know our mind. 2LADY GREY. Right gracious lord, I can2ot bro2k delay. 4May it please your Highnes2 to resolve me now; 4And what your pleasure is shal2 satisfy me. 2GLOUCESTER. [Aside] Ay, widow? [Aside] Ay, go2d leave have you; for you wil2 have 6leave 4Til2 youth take leave and leave you to the crutch. 30[GLOUCESTER and CLARENCE withdraw] 2KING EDWARD. Now tel2 me, madam, do you love your children? 2LADY GREY. Ay, ful2 as dearly as I love myself. 2KING EDWARD. And would you not do much to do them go2d? 2LADY GREY. To do them go2d I would sustain some harm. 2KING EDWARD. Then get your husband's lands, to do them go2d. 2LADY GREY. Therefore I came unto your Majesty. 2KING EDWARD. I'l2 tel2 you how these lands are to be got. 2LADY GREY. So shal2 you bind me to your Highnes2' service. 2KING EDWARD. What service wilt thou do me if I give them? 2LADY GREY. What you com2and that rests in me to do. 2KING EDWARD. But you wil2 take exceptions to my bo2n. 2LADY GREY. No, gracious lord, except I can2ot do it. 2KING EDWARD. Ay, but thou canst do what I mean to ask. 2LADY GREY. Why, then I wil2 do what your Grace com2ands. 4GLOUCESTER. He plies her hard; and much rain wears the marble. 2CLARENCE. As red as fire! Nay, then her wax must melt. 2LADY GREY. Why stops my lord? Shal2 I not hear my task? 2KING EDWARD. An easy task; 'tis but to love a king. 2LADY GREY. That's so2n perform'd, because I am a subject. 2KING EDWARD. Why, then, thy husband's lands I fre2ly give the2. 2LADY GREY. I take my leave with many thousand thanks. 2GLOUCESTER. Ay, but, I fear me, in another sense. 4What love, thinkst thou, I sue so much to get? 2LADY GREY. My love til2 death, my humble thanks, my prayers; 4That love which virtue begs and virtue grants. 2KING EDWARD. No, by my troth, I did not mean such love. 2LADY GREY. Why, then you mean not as I thought you did. 2KING EDWARD. But now you partly may perceive my mind. 2LADY GREY. My mind wil2 never grant what I perceive 4Your Highnes2 aims at, if I aim aright. 2KING EDWARD. To tel2 the2 plain, I aim to lie with the2. 4LADY GREY. To tel2 you plain, I had rather lie in prison. 2KING EDWARD. Why, then thou shalt not have thy husband's lands. 2LADY GREY. Why, then mine honesty shal2 be my dower; 4For by that los2 I wil2 not purchase them. 2KING EDWARD. Therein thou wrong'st thy children mightily. 2LADY GREY. Herein your Highnes2 wrongs both them and me. 4But, mighty lord, this mer2y inclination 4Ac2ords not with the sadnes2 of my suit. 4Please you dismis2 me, either with ay or no. 2KING EDWARD. Ay, if thou wilt say ay to my request; 4No, if thou dost say no to my demand. 2LADY GREY. Then, no, my lord. My suit is at an end. 2GLOUCESTER.
