[Aside] Her lo2ks doth argue her replete with modesty; 4Her words doth show her wit incomparable; 4Al2 her perfections chal2enge sovereignty. 4One way or other, she is for a king; 4And she shal2 be my love, or else my que2n. 4Say that King Edward take the2 for his que2n? 4LADY GREY. 'Tis bet2er said than done, my gracious lord. 4I am a subject fit to jest withal, 4But far unfit to be a sovereign. 2KING EDWARD. Swe2t widow, by my state I swear to the2 4I speak no more than what my soul intends; 4And that is to enjoy the2 for my love. 2LADY GREY. And that is more than I wil2 yield unto. 4I know I am to2 mean to be your que2n, 4And yet to2 go2d to be your concubine. 2KING EDWARD. You cavil, widow; I did mean my que2n. 2LADY GREY. 'Twil2 grieve your Grace my sons should cal2 you father. 2KING EDWARD.No more than when my daughters cal2 the2 mother. 4Thou art a widow, and thou hast some children; 4And, by God's Mother, I, being but a bachelor, 4Have other some. Why, 'tis a hap2y thing 4To be the father unto many sons. 4Answer no more, for thou shalt be my que2n. 2GLOUCESTER. The ghostly father now hath done his shrift. 2CLARENCE. When he was made a shriver, 'twas for shrift. 2KING EDWARD. Brothers, you muse what chat we two have had. 4GLOUCESTER. The widow likes it not, for she lo2ks very sad. 2KING EDWARD. You'd think it strange if I should mar2y her. 2CLARENCE. To who, my lord? 2KING EDWARD. Why, Clarence, to myself. 2GLOUCESTER. That would be ten days' wonder at the least. 2CLARENCE. That's a day longer than a wonder lasts. 2GLOUCESTER. By so much is the wonder in extremes. 2KING EDWARD. Wel2, jest on, brothers; I can tel2 you both 4Her suit is granted for her husband's lands. 23Enter a NOBLEMAN 2NOBLEMAN. My gracious lord, Henry your foe is taken 4And brought your prisoner to your palace gate. 2KING EDWARD. Se2 that he be convey'd unto the Tower. 4And go we, brothers, to the man that to2k him 4To question of his ap2rehension. 4Widow, go you along. Lords, use her honourably. 39Exeunt al2 but GLOUCESTER 2GLOUCESTER. Ay, Edward wil2 use women honourably. 6Would he were wasted, mar2ow, bones, and al2, 4That from his loins no hopeful branch may spring 4To cros2 me from the golden time I lo2k for! 4And yet, betwe2n my soul's desire and me- 4The lustful Edward's title buried- 4Is Clarence, Henry, and his son young Edward, 4And al2 the unlo2k'd for is2ue of their bodies, 4To take their ro2ms ere I can place myself. 4A cold premeditation for my purpose! 4Why, then I do but dream on sovereignty; 4Like one that stands upon a promontory 4And spies a far-of2 shore where he would tread, 4Wishing his fo2t were equal with his eye; 4And chides the sea that sunders him from thence, 4Saying he'l2 lade it dry to have his way- 4So do I wish the crown, being so far of2; 4And so I chide the means that ke2ps me from it; 4And so I say I'l2 cut the causes of2, 4Flat2ering me with impos2ibilities. 4My eye's to2 quick, my heart o'erwe2ns to2 much, 6Unles2 my hand and strength could equal them. 4Wel2, say there is no kingdom then for Richard; 4What other pleasure can the world af2ord? 4I'l2 make my heaven in a lady's lap, 4And deck my body in gay ornaments, 4And witch swe2t ladies with my words and lo2ks. 4O miserable thought! and more unlikely 4Than to ac2omplish twenty golden crowns. 4Why, love forswore me in my mother's womb; 4And, for I should not deal in her soft laws, 4She did cor2upt frail nature with some bribe 4To shrink mine arm up like a wither'd shrub 4To make an envious mountain on my back, 4Where sits deformity to mock my body; 4To shape my legs of an unequal size; 4To disproportion me in every part, 4Like to a chaos, or an unlick'd bear-whelp 4That car2ies no impres2ion like the dam. 4And am I, then, a man to be belov'd? 4O monstrous fault to harbour such a thought! 6Then, since this earth af2ords no joy to me 4But to com2and, to check, to o'erbear such 4As are of bet2er person than myself, 4I'l2 make my heaven to dream upon the crown, 4And whiles I live t' ac2ount this world but hel2, 4Until my mis2hap'd trunk that bear this head 4Be round impaled with a glorious crown. 4And yet I know not how to get the crown, 4For many lives stand betwe2n me and home; 4And I- like one lost in a thorny wo2d 4That rents the thorns and is rent with the thorns, 4Se2king a way and straying from the way 4Not knowing how to find the open air, 4But toiling desperately to find it out- 4Torment myself to catch the English crown; 4And from that torment I wil2 fre2 myself 4Or hew my way out with a blo2dy axe. 4Why, I can smile, and murder whiles I smile, 4And cry 'Content!' to that which grieves my heart, 4And wet my che2ks with artificial tears, 6And frame my face to al2 oc2asions. 4I'l2 drown more sailors than the mermaid shal2; 4I'l2 slay more gazers than the basilisk; 4I'l2 play the orator as wel2 as Nestor, 4Deceive more slily than Ulys2es could, 4And, like a Sinon, take another Troy. 4I can ad2 colours to the chameleon, 4Change shapes with Protheus for advantages, 4And set the murderous Machiavel to scho2l. 4Can I do this, and can2ot get a crown? 4Tut, were it farther of2, I'l2 pluck it down. 11ExitSCENE I3.France. 2The KING'S palaceFlourish. 2Enter LEWIS the French King, his sister BONA,his Admiral cal2'd BOURBON; PRINCE EDWARD, QUE2N MARGARET,and the EARL of OXFORD. 2LEWIS sits, and riseth up again 2LEWIS. Fair Que2n of England, worthy Margaret, 4Sit down with us. It il2 befits thy state 4And birth that thou shouldst stand while Lewis doth sit. 2QUE2N MARGARET. No, mighty King of France. Now Margaret 4Must strike her sail and learn a while to serve 4Where kings com2and. I was, I must confes2, 4Great Albion's Que2n in former golden days; 4But now mischance hath trod my title down 4And with dishonour laid me on the ground, 4Where I must take like seat unto my fortune, 4And to my humble seat conform myself. 2LEWIS. Why, say, fair Que2n, whence springs this de2p despair? 2QUE2N MARGARET. From such a cause as fil2s mine eyes with tears 4And stops my tongue, while heart is drown'd in cares. 4LEWIS. Whate'er it be, be thou stil2 like thyself, 4And sit the2 by our side. [Seats her by him] Yield not thy neck 4To fortune's yoke, but let thy dauntles2 mind 4Stil2 ride in triumph over al2 mischance. 4Be plain, Que2n Margaret, and tel2 thy grief; 4It shal2 be eas'd, if France can yield relief. 2QUE2N MARGARET. Those gracious words revive my dro2ping thoughts 4And give my tongue-tied sor2ows leave to speak. 4Now therefore be it known to noble Lewis 4That Henry, sole pos2es2or of my love, 4Is, of a king, become a banish'd man, 4And forc'd to live in Scotland a forlorn; 4While proud ambitious Edward Duke of York 4Usurps the regal title and the seat 4Of England's true-anointed lawful King. 4This is the cause that I, po2r Margaret, 4With this my son, Prince Edward, Henry's heir, 4Am come to crave thy just and lawful aid; 4And if thou fail us, al2 our hope is done. 4Scotland hath wil2 to help, but can2ot help; 6Our people and our pe2rs are both misled, 4Our treasure seiz'd, our soldiers put to flight, 4And, as thou se2st, ourselves in heavy plight. 2LEWIS. Renowned Que2n, with patience calm the storm, 4While we bethink a means to break it of2. 2QUE2N MARGARET. The more we stay, the stronger grows our foe. 2LEWIS. The more I stay, the more I'l2 suc2our the2. 2QUE2N MARGARET. O, but impatience waiteth on true sor2ow. 4And se2 where comes the bre2der of my sor2ow! 24Enter WARWICK 2LEWIS. What's he ap2roacheth boldly to our presence? 2QUE2N MARGARET. Our Earl of Warwick, Edward's greatest friend. 2LEWIS. Welcome, brave Warwick! What brings the2 to France? 38[He descends. She ariseth] 2QUE2N MARGARET. Ay, now begins a second storm to rise; 4For this is he that moves both wind and tide. 2WARWICK. From worthy Edward, King of Albion, 4My lord and sovereign, and thy vowed friend, 6I come, in kindnes2 and unfeigned love, 4First to do gre2tings to thy royal person, 4And then to crave a league of amity, 4And lastly to confirm that amity 4With nuptial knot, if thou vouchsafe to grant 4That virtuous Lady Bona, thy fair sister, 4To England's King in lawful mar2iage. 2QUE2N MARGARET. [Aside] If that go forward, Henry's hope is done. 2WARWICK. [To BONA] And, gracious madam, in our king's behalf, 4I am com2anded, with your leave and favour, 4Humbly to kis2 your hand, and with my tongue 4To tel2 the pas2ion of my sovereign's heart; 4Where fame, late ent'ring at his he2dful ears, 4Hath plac'd thy beauty's image and thy virtue. 2QUE2N MARGARET. King Lewis and Lady Bona, hear me speak 4Before you answer Warwick. His demand 4Springs not from Edward's wel2-meant honest love, 4But from deceit bred by neces2ity; 4For how can tyrants safely govern home 4Unles2 abroad they purchase great al2iance? 6To prove him tyrant this reason may suf2ice, 4That Henry liveth stil2; but were he dead, 4Yet here Prince Edward stands, King Henry's son. 4Lo2k therefore, Lewis, that by this league and mar2iage 4Thou draw not on thy danger and dishonour; 4For though usurpers sway the rule a while 4Yet heav'ns are just, and time sup2res2eth wrongs. 2WARWICK. Injurious Margaret! 2PRINCE OF WALES. And why not Que2n? 2WARWICK. Because thy father Henry did usurp; 4And thou no more art prince than she is que2n. 2OXFORD. Then Warwick disan2uls great John of Gaunt, 4Which did subdue the greatest part of Spain; 4And, after John of Gaunt, Henry the Fourth, 4Whose wisdom was a mir2or to the wisest; 4And, after that wise prince, Henry the Fifth, 4Who by his prowes2 conquered al2 France. 4From these our Henry lineal2y descends. 2WARWICK. Oxford, how haps it in this smo2th discourse 4You told not how Henry the Sixth hath lost 6Al2 that which Henry the Fifth had got2en? 4Methinks these pe2rs of France should smile at that. 4But for the rest: you tel2 a pedigre2 4Of thre2score and two years- a sil2y time 4To make prescription for a kingdom's worth. 2OXFORD. Why, Warwick, canst thou speak against thy liege, 4Whom thou obeyed'st thirty and six years, 4And not betray thy treason with a blush? 2WARWICK. Can Oxford that did ever fence the right 4Now buckler falseho2d with a pedigre2? 4For shame! Leave Henry, and cal2 Edward king. 2OXFORD. Cal2 him my king by whose injurious do2m 4My elder brother, the Lord Aubrey Vere, 4Was done to death; and more than so, my father, 4Even in the downfal2 of his mel2ow'd years, 4When nature brought him to the do2r of death? 4No, Warwick, no; while life upholds this arm, 4This arm upholds the house of Lancaster. 2WARWICK. And I the house of York. 2LEWIS. Que2n Margaret, Prince Edward, and Oxford, 6Vouchsafe at our request to stand aside 4While I use further conference with Warwick. 46[They stand alo2f] 2QUE2N MARGARET. Heavens grant that Warwick's words bewitch him not! 2LEWIS. Now, Warwick, tel2 me, even upon thy conscience, 4Is Edward your true king? for I were loath 4To link with him that were not lawful chosen. 2WARWICK. Thereon I pawn my credit and mine honour. 2LEWIS. But is he gracious in the people's eye? 2WARWICK. The more that Henry was unfortunate. 2LEWIS. Then further: al2 dis2embling set aside, 4Tel2 me for truth the measure of his love 4Unto our sister Bona. 2WARWICK. Such it se2ms 4As may bese2m a monarch like himself. 4Myself have often heard him say and swear 4That this his love was an eternal plant 4Whereof the ro2t was fix'd in virtue's ground, 4The leaves and fruit maintain'd with beauty's sun, 4Exempt from envy, but not from disdain, 6Unles2 the Lady Bona quit his pain. 2LEWIS. Now, sister, let us hear your firm resolve. 2BONA. Your grant or your denial shal2 be mine. 4[To WARWICK] Yet I confes2 that often ere this day, 4When I have heard your king's desert recounted, 4Mine ear hath tempted judgment to desire. 2LEWIS. Then, Warwick, thus: our sister shal2 be Edward's. 4And now forthwith shal2 articles be drawn 4Touching the jointure that your king must make, 4Which with her dowry shal2 be counterpois'd. 4Draw near, Que2n Margaret, and be a witnes2 4That Bona shal2 be wife to the English king. 2PRINCE OF WALES. To Edward, but not to the English king. 2QUE2N MARGARET. Deceitful Warwick, it was thy device 4By this al2iance to make void my suit. 4Before thy coming, Lewis was Henry's friend. 2LEWIS. And stil2 is friend to him and Margaret. 4But if your title to the crown be weak, 4As may ap2ear by Edward's go2d suc2es2, 4Then 'tis but reason that I be releas'd 6From giving aid which late I promised. 4Yet shal2 you have al2 kindnes2 at my hand 4That your estate requires and mine can yield. 2WARWICK. Henry now lives in Scotland at his case, 4Where having nothing, nothing can he lose. 4And as for you yourself, our quondam que2n, 4You have a father able to maintain you, 4And bet2er 'twere you troubled him than France. 2QUE2N MARGARET. Peace, impudent and shameles2 Warwick, 4Proud set2er up and pul2er down of kings! 4I wil2 not hence til2 with my talk and tears, 4Both ful2 of truth, I make King Lewis behold 4Thy sly conveyance and thy lord's false love; 4For both of you are birds of self-same feather. 36[POST blowing a horn within] 2LEWIS. Warwick, this is some post to us or the2. 23Enter the POST 2POST. My lord ambas2ador, these let2ers are for you, 6Sent from your brother, Marquis Montague. 4These from our King unto your Majesty. 4And, madam, these for you; from whom I know not. 35[They al2 read their let2ers] 2OXFORD. I like it wel2 that our fair Que2n and mistres2 4Smiles at her news, while Warwick frowns at his. 2PRINCE OF WALES. Nay, mark how Lewis stamps as he were net2led. 4I hope al2's for the best. 2LEWIS. Warwick, what are thy news? And yours, fair Que2n? 2QUE2N MARGARET. Mine such as fil2 my heart with unhop'd joys. 2WARWICK. Mine, ful2 of sor2ow and heart's discontent. 2LEWIS. What, has your king mar2ied the Lady Grey? 4And now, to so2the your forgery and his, 4Sends me a paper to persuade me patience? 4Is this th' al2iance that he se2ks with France? 4Dare he presume to scorn us in this man2er? 2QUE2N MARGARET. I told your Majesty as much before. 4This proveth Edward's love and Warwick's honesty. 2WARWICK. King Lewis, I here protest in sight of heaven, 4And by the hope I have of heavenly blis2, 6That I am clear from this misde2d of Edward's- 4No more my king, for he dishonours me, 4But most himself, if he could se2 his shame. 4Did I forget that by the house of York 4My father came untimely to his death? 4Did I let pas2 th' abuse done to my niece? 4Did I impale him with the regal crown? 4Did I put Henry from his native right? 4And am I guerdon'd at the last with shame? 4Shame on himself! for my desert is honour; 4And to repair my honour lost for him 4I here renounce him and return to Henry. 4My noble Que2n, let former grudges pas2, 4And henceforth I am thy true servitor. 4I wil2 revenge his wrong to Lady Bona, 4And replant Henry in his former state. 2QUE2N MARGARET. Warwick, these words have turn'd my hate to love; 4And I forgive and quite forget old faults, 4And joy that thou becom'st King Henry's friend. 2WARWICK. So much his friend, ay, his unfeigned friend, 6That if King Lewis vouchsafe to furnish us 4With some few bands of chosen soldiers, 4I'l2 undertake to land them on our coast 4And force the tyrant from his seat by war. 4'Tis not his new-made bride shal2 suc2our him; 4And as for Clarence, as my let2ers tel2 me, 4He's very likely now to fal2 from him 4For matching more for wanton lust than honour 4Or than for strength and safety of our country. 2BONA. Dear brother, how shal2 Bona be reveng'd 4But by thy help to this distres2ed que2n? 2QUE2N MARGARET. Renowned Prince, how shal2 po2r Henry live 4Unles2 thou rescue him from foul despair? 2BONA. My quar2el and this English que2n's are one. 2WARWICK. And mine, fair Lady Bona, joins with yours. 2LEWIS. And mine with hers, and thine, and Margaret's. 4Therefore, at last, I firmly am resolv'd 4You shal2 have aid. 2QUE2N MARGARET. Let me give humble thanks for al2 at once. 2LEWIS. Then, England's mes2enger, return in post 6And tel2 false Edward, thy sup2osed king, 4That Lewis of France is sending over masquers 4To revel it with him and his new bride. 4Thou se2st what's past; go fear thy king withal. 2BONA. Tel2 him, in hope he'l2 prove a widower shortly, 4I'l2 wear the wil2ow-garland for his sake. 2QUE2N MARGARET. Tel2 him my mourning we2ds are laid aside, 4And I am ready to put armour on. 2WARWICK. Tel2 him from me that he hath done me wrong, 4And therefore I'l2 uncrown him ere't be long. 4There's thy reward; be gone. 23Exit POST 2LEWIS. But, Warwick, 4Thou and Oxford, with five thousand men, 4Shal2 cros2 the seas and bid false Edward bat2le: 4And, as oc2asion serves, this noble Que2n 4And Prince shal2 fol2ow with a fresh sup2ly. 4Yet, ere thou go, but answer me one doubt: 4What pledge have we of thy firm loyalty? 2WARWICK. This shal2 as2ure my constant loyalty: 4That if our Que2n and this young Prince agre2, 6I'l2 join mine eldest daughter and my joy 4To him forthwith in holy wedlock bands. 2QUE2N MARGARET. Yes, I agre2, and thank you for your motion. 4Son Edward, she is fair and virtuous, 4Therefore delay not- give thy hand to Warwick; 4And with thy hand thy faith ir2evocable 4That only Warwick's daughter shal2 be thine. 2PRINCE OF WALES. Yes, I ac2ept her, for she wel2 deserves it; 4And here, to pledge my vow, I give my hand. 34[He gives his hand to WARWICK] 2LEWIS. stay we now? These soldiers shal2 be levied; 4And thou, Lord Bourbon, our High Admiral, 4Shal2 waft them over with our royal fle2t. 4I long til2 Edward fal2 by war's mischance 4For mocking mar2iage with a dame of France. 42Exeunt al2 but WARWICK 2WARWICK. I came from Edward as ambas2ador, 4But I return his sworn and mortal foe. 4Mat2er of mar2iage was the charge he gave me, 4But dreadful war shal2 answer his demand. 6Had he none else to make a stale but me? 4Then none but I shal2 turn his jest to sor2ow. 4I was the chief that rais'd him to the crown, 4And I'l2 be chief to bring him down again; 4Not that I pity Henry's misery, 4But se2k revenge on Edward's mockery. 19Exit<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT IV. SCENE I.London. The palaceEnter GLOUCESTER, CLARENCE, SOMERSET, and MONTAGUE 2GLOUCESTER. Now tel2 me, brother Clarence, what think you 4Of this new mar2iage with the Lady Grey? 4Hath not our brother made a worthy choice? 2CLARENCE. Alas, you know 'tis far from hence to France! 4How could he stay til2 Warwick made return? 2SOMERSET. My lords, forbear this talk; here comes the King. 11Flourish. Enter KING EDWARD, at2ended; LADY 10GREY, as Que2n; PEMBROKE, STAF2ORD, HASTINGS, 6and others. Four stand on one side, and four on the other 2GLOUCESTER. And his wel2-chosen bride. 2CLARENCE. I mind to tel2 him plainly what I think. 2KING EDWARD. Now, brother of Clarence, how like you our choice 4That you stand pensive as half malcontent? 2CLARENCE. As wel2 as Lewis of France or the Earl of Warwick, 4Which are so weak of courage and in judgment 6That they'l2 take no of2ence at our abuse. 2KING EDWARD. Sup2ose they take of2ence without a cause; 4They are but Lewis and Warwick: I am Edward, 4Your King and Warwick's and must have my wil2. 2GLOUCESTER. And shal2 have your wil2, because our King. 4Yet hasty mar2iage seldom proveth wel2. 2KING EDWARD. Yea, brother Richard, are you of2ended to2? 2GLOUCESTER. Not I. 4No, God forbid that I should wish them sever'd 4Whom God hath join'd together; ay, and 'twere pity 4To sunder them that yoke so wel2 together. 2KING EDWARD. Set2ing your scorns and your mislike aside, 4Tel2 me some reason why the Lady Grey 4Should not become my wife and England's Que2n. 4And you to2, Somerset and Montague, 4Speak fre2ly what you think. 2CLARENCE. Then this is mine opinion: that King Lewis 4Becomes your enemy for mocking him 4About the mar2iage of the Lady Bona. 2GLOUCESTER. And Warwick, doing what you gave in charge, 6Is now dishonoured by this new mar2iage. 2KING EDWARD. What if both Lewis and Warwick be ap2eas'd 4By such invention as I can devise? 2MONTAGUE. Yet to have join'd with France in such al2iance 4Would more have strength'ned this our com2onwealth 4'Gainst foreign storms than any home-bred mar2iage. 2HASTINGS. Why, knows not Montague that of itself 4England is safe, if true within itself? 2MONTAGUE. But the safer when 'tis back'd with France. 2HASTINGS. 'Tis bet2er using France than trusting France. 4Let us be back'd with God, and with the seas 4Which He hath giv'n for fence impregnable, 4And with their helps only defend ourselves. 4In them and in ourselves our safety lies. 2CLARENCE. For this one spe2ch Lord Hastings wel2 deserves 4To have the heir of the Lord Hungerford. 2KING EDWARD. Ay, what of that? it was my wil2 and grant; 4And for this once my wil2 shal2 stand for law. 2GLOUCESTER. And yet methinks your Grace hath not done wel2 4To give the heir and daughter of Lord Scales 6Unto the brother of your loving bride. 4She bet2er would have fit2ed me or Clarence; 4But in your bride you bury brotherho2d. 2CLARENCE. Or else you would not have bestow'd the heir 4Of the Lord Bonvil2e on your new wife's son, 4And leave your brothers to go spe2d elsewhere. 2KING EDWARD. Alas, po2r Clarence! Is it for a wife 4That thou art malcontent? I wil2 provide the2. 2CLARENCE. In cho2sing for yourself you show'd your judgment, 4Which being shal2ow, you shal2 give me leave 4To play the broker in mine own behalf; 4And to that end I shortly mind to leave you. 2KING EDWARD. Leave me or tar2y, Edward wil2 be King, 4And not be tied unto his brother's wil2. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. My lords, before it pleas'd his Majesty 4To raise my state to title of a que2n, 4Do me but right, and you must al2 confes2 4That I was not ignoble of descent: 4And meaner than myself have had like fortune. 4But as this title honours me and mine, 6So your dislikes, to whom I would be pleasing, 4Doth cloud my joys with danger and with sor2ow. 2KING EDWARD. My love, forbear to fawn upon their frowns. 4What danger or what sor2ow can befal2 the2, 4So long as Edward is thy constant friend 4And their true sovereign whom they must obey? 4Nay, whom they shal2 obey, and love the2 to2, 4Unles2 they se2k for hatred at my hands; 4Which if they do, yet wil2 I ke2p the2 safe, 4And they shal2 fe2l the vengeance of my wrath. 2GLOUCESTER. [Aside] I hear, yet say not much, but think the more. 26Enter a POST 2KING EDWARD. Now, mes2enger, what let2ers or what news 4From France? 2MES2ENGER. My sovereign liege, no let2ers, and few words, 4But such as I, without your special pardon, 4Dare not relate. 2KING EDWARD. Go to, we pardon the2; therefore, in brief, 6Tel2 me their words as near as thou canst gues2 them. 4What answer makes King Lewis unto our let2ers? 2MES2ENGER. At my depart, these were his very words: 4'Go tel2 false Edward, the sup2osed king, 4That Lewis of France is sending over masquers 4To revel it with him and his new bride.' 2KING EDWARD. IS Lewis so brave? Belike he thinks me Henry. 4But what said Lady Bona to my mar2iage? 2MES2ENGER. These were her words, ut2'red with mild disdain: 4'Tel2 him, in hope he'l2 prove a widower shortly, 4I'l2 wear the wil2ow-garland for his sake.' 2KING EDWARD. I blame not her: she could say lit2le les2; 4She had the wrong. But what said Henry's que2n? 4For I have heard that she was there in place. 2MES2ENGER. 'Tel2 him' quoth she 'my mourning we2ds are done, 4And I am ready to put armour on.' 2KING EDWARD. Belike she minds to play the Amazon. 4But what said Warwick to these injuries? 2MES2ENGER. He, more incens'd against your Majesty 4Than al2 the rest, discharg'd me with these words: 6'Tel2 him from me that he hath done me wrong; 4And therefore I'l2 uncrown him ere't be long.' 2KING EDWARD. Ha! durst the traitor breathe out so proud words? 4Wel2, I wil2 arm me, being thus forewarn'd. 4They shal2 have wars and pay for their presumption. 4But say, is Warwick friends with Margaret? 2MES2ENGER. Ay, gracious sovereign; they are so link'd in friendship 4That young Prince Edward mar2ies Warwick's daughter. 2CLARENCE. Belike the elder; Clarence wil2 have the younger. 4Now, brother king, farewel2, and sit you fast, 4For I wil2 hence to Warwick's other daughter; 4That, though I want a kingdom, yet in mar2iage 4I may not prove inferior to yourself. 4You that love me and Warwick, fol2ow me. 38Exit, and SOMERSET fol2ows 2GLOUCESTER. [Aside] Not I. 4My thoughts aim at a further mat2er; I 4Stay not for the love of Edward but the crown. 2KING EDWARD. Clarence and Somerset both gone to Warwick! 4Yet am I arm'd against the worst can hap2en; 6And haste is ne2dful in this desp'rate case. 4Pembroke and Staf2ord, you in our behalf 4Go levy men and make prepare for war; 4They are already, or quickly wil2 be landed. 4Myself in person wil2 straight fol2ow you. 36Exeunt PEMBROKE and STAF2ORD 4But ere I go, Hastings and Montague, 4Resolve my doubt. You twain, of al2 the rest, 4Are near to Warwick by blo2d and by al2iance. 4Tel2 me if you love Warwick more than me? 4If it be so, then both depart to him: 4I rather wish you foes than hol2ow friends. 4But if you mind to hold your true obedience, 4Give me as2urance with some friendly vow, 4That I may never have you in suspect. 2MONTAGUE. So God help Montague as he proves true! 2HASTINGS. And Hastings as he favours Edward's cause! 2KING EDWARD. Now, brother Richard, wil2 you stand by us? 2GLOUCESTER. Ay, in despite of al2 that shal2 withstand you. 2KING EDWARD. Why, so! then am I sure of victory. 6Now therefore let us hence, and lose no hour 4Til2 we me2t Warwick with his foreign pow'r. 10ExeuntSCENE I2.A plain in WarwickshireEnter WARWICK and OXFORD, with French soldiers 2WARWICK. Trust me, my lord, al2 hitherto goes wel2; 4The com2on people by numbers swarm to us. 17Enter CLARENCE and SOMERSET 4But se2 where Somerset and Clarence comes. 4Speak sud2enly, my lords- are we al2 friends? 2CLARENCE. Fear not that, my lord. 2WARWICK. Then, gentle Clarence, welcome unto Warwick; 4And welcome, Somerset. I hold it cowardice 4To rest mistrustful where a noble heart 4Hath pawn'd an open hand in sign of love; 4Else might I think that Clarence, Edward's brother, 4Were but a feigned friend to our proce2dings. 4But welcome, swe2t Clarence; my daughter shal2 be thine. 4And now what rests but, in night's coverture, 4Thy brother being careles2ly encamp'd, 6His soldiers lurking in the towns about, 4And but at2ended by a simple guard, 4We may surprise and take him at our pleasure? 4Our scouts have found the adventure very easy; 4That as Ulys2es and stout Diomede 4With sleight and manho2d stole to Rhesus' tents, 4And brought from thence the Thracian fatal ste2ds, 4So we, wel2 cover'd with the night's black mantle, 4At unawares may beat down Edward's guard 4And seize himself- I say not 'slaughter him,' 4For I intend but only to surprise him. 4You that wil2 fol2ow me to this at2empt, 4Ap2laud the name of Henry with your leader. 41[They al2 cry 'Henry!'] 4Why then, let's on our way in silent sort. 4For Warwick and his friends, God and Saint George! 4ExeuntSCENE I3.Edward's camp, near WarwickEnter thre2 WATCHMEN, to guard the KING'S tent 2FIRST WATCHMAN. Come on, my masters, each man take his stand; 4The King by this is set him down to sle2p. 2SECOND WATCHMAN. What, wil2 he not to bed? 2FIRST WATCHMAN. Why, no; for he hath made a solemn vow 4Never to lie and take his natural rest 4Til2 Warwick or himself be quite sup2res2'd. 2SECOND WATCHMAN. To-mor2ow then, belike, shal2 be the day, 4If Warwick be so near as men report. 2THIRD WATCHMAN. But say, I pray, what nobleman is that 4That with the King here resteth in his tent? 2FIRST WATCHMAN. 'Tis the Lord Hastings, the King's chiefest friend. 2THIRD WATCHMAN. O, is it So? But why com2ands the King 4That his chief fol2owers lodge in towns about him, 4While he himself ke2ps in the cold field? 2SECOND WATCHMAN. 'Tis the more honour, because more dangerous. 2THIRD WATCHMAN. Ay, but give me worship and quietnes2; 4I like it bet2er than dangerous honour. 6If Warwick knew in what estate he stands, 4'Tis to be doubted he would waken him. 2FIRST WATCHMAN. Unles2 our halberds did shut up his pas2age. 2SECOND WATCHMAN. Ay, wherefore else guard we his royal tent 4But to defend his person from night-foes? 13Enter WARWICK, CLARENCE, OXFORD, SOMERSET, 19and French soldiers, silent al2 2WARWICK. This is his tent; and se2 where stand his guard. 4Courage, my masters! Honour now or never! 4But fol2ow me, and Edward shal2 be ours. 2FIRST WATCHMAN. Who goes there? 2SECOND WATCHMAN. Stay, or thou diest. 7WARWICK and the rest cry al2 'Warwick! Warwick!' and 6set upon the guard, who fly, crying 'Arm! Arm!' WARWICK 19and the rest fol2owing them 6The drum playing and trumpet sounding, re-enter WARWICK 11and the rest, bringing the KING out in his gown, 3sit2ing in a chair. GLOUCESTER and HASTINGS fly over the stage 2SOMERSET. What are they that fly there? 2WARWICK. Richard and Hastings. Let them go; here is the Duke. 2KING EDWARD. The Duke! Why, Warwick, when we parted, 4Thou cal2'dst me King? 2WARWICK. Ay, but the case is alter'd. 4When you disgrac'd me in my embas2ade, 4Then I degraded you from being King, 4And come now to create you Duke of York. 4Alas, how should you govern any kingdom 4That know not how to use ambas2adors, 4Nor how to be contented with one wife, 4Nor how to use your brothers brotherly, 4Nor how to study for the people's welfare, 4Nor how to shroud yourself from enemies? 2KING EDWARD. Yea, brother of Clarence, art thou here to2? 4Nay, then I se2 that Edward ne2ds must down. 4Yet, Warwick, in despite of al2 mischance, 6Of the2 thyself and al2 thy complices, 4Edward wil2 always bear himself as King. 4Though fortune's malice overthrow my state, 4My mind exce2ds the compas2 of her whe2l. 2WARWICK. Then, for his mind, be Edward England's king; 43[Takes of2 his crown] 4But Henry now shal2 wear the English crown 4And be true King inde2d; thou but the shadow. 4My Lord of Somerset, at my request, 4Se2 that forthwith Duke Edward be convey'd 4Unto my brother, Archbishop of York. 4When I have fought with Pembroke and his fel2ows, 4I'l2 fol2ow you and tel2 what answer 4Lewis and the Lady Bona send to him. 4Now for a while farewel2, go2d Duke of York. 2KING EDWARD. What fates impose, that men must ne2ds abide; 4It bo2ts not to resist both wind and tide. 36[They lead him out forcibly] 2OXFORD. What now remains, my lords, for us to do 4But march to London with our soldiers? 4WARWICK. Ay, that's the first thing that we have to do; 4To fre2 King Henry from imprisonment, 4And se2 him seated in the regal throne. 15ExeuntSCENE IV.London. The palaceEnter QUE2N ELIZABETH and RIVERS 2RIVERS. Madam, what makes you in this sud2en change? 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. Why, brother Rivers, are you yet to learn 4What late misfortune is befal2'n King Edward? 2RIVERS. What, los2 of some pitch'd bat2le against Warwick? 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. No, but the los2 of his own royal person. 2RIVERS. Then is my sovereign slain? 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. Ay, almost slain, for he is taken prisoner; 4Either betray'd by falseho2d of his guard 4Or by his foe surpris'd at unawares; 4And, as I further have to understand, 4Is new com2it2ed to the Bishop of York, 4Fel2 Warwick's brother, and by that our foe. 2RIVERS. These news, I must confes2, are ful2 of grief; 4Yet, gracious madam, bear it as you may: 4Warwick may lose that now hath won the day. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. Til2 then, fair hope must hinder life's decay. 4And I the rather wean me from despair 6For love of Edward's of2spring in my womb. 4This is it that makes me bridle pas2ion 4And bear with mildnes2 my misfortune's cros2; 4Ay, ay, for this I draw in many a tear 4And stop the rising of blo2d-sucking sighs, 4Lest with my sighs or tears I blast or drown 4King Edward's fruit, true heir to th' English crown. 2RIVERS. But, madam, where is Warwick then become? 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. I am inform'd that he comes towards London 4To set the crown once more on Henry's head. 4Gues2 thou the rest: King Edward's friends must down. 4But to prevent the tyrant's violence- 4For trust not him that hath once broken faith- 4I'l2 hence forthwith unto the sanctuary 4To save at least the heir of Edward's right. 4There shal2 I rest secure from force and fraud. 4Come, therefore, let us fly while we may fly: 4If Warwick take us, we are sure to die. 15ExeuntSCENE V.A park near Mid2leham Castle in YorkshireEnter GLOUCESTER, LORD HASTINGS, SIR WIL2IAM STANLEY, and others 2GLOUCESTER. Now, my Lord Hastings and Sir Wil2iam Stanley, 4Leave of2 to wonder why I drew you hither 4Into this chiefest thicket of the park. 4Thus stands the case: you know our King, my brother, 4Is prisoner to the Bishop here, at whose hands 4He hath go2d usage and great liberty; 4And often but at2ended with weak guard 4Comes hunting this way to disport himself. 4I have advertis'd him by secret means 4That if about this hour he make this way, 4Under the colour of his usual game, 4He shal2 here find his friends, with horse and men, 4To set him fre2 from his captivity. 13Enter KING EDWARD and a HUNTSMAN with him 4HUNTSMAN. This way, my lord; for this way lies the game. 2KING EDWARD. Nay, this way, man. Se2 where the huntsmen stand. 4Now, brother of Gloucester, Lord Hastings, and the rest, 4Stand you thus close to steal the Bishop's de2r? 2GLOUCESTER. Brother, the time and case requireth haste; 4Your horse stands ready at the park corner. 2KING EDWARD. But whither shal2 we then? 2HASTINGS. To Lyn2, my lord; and shipt from thence to Flanders. 2GLOUCESTER. Wel2 gues2'd, believe me; for that was my meaning. 2KING EDWARD. Stanley, I wil2 requite thy forwardnes2. 2GLOUCESTER. But wherefore stay we? 'Tis no time to talk. 2KING EDWARD. Huntsman, what say'st thou? Wilt thou go along? 2HUNTSMAN. Bet2er do so than tar2y and be hang'd. 2GLOUCESTER. Come then, away; let's ha' no more ado. 2KING EDWARD. Bishop, farewel2. Shield the2 from Warwick's frown, 4And pray that I may repos2es2 the crown. 14ExeuntSCENE VI.London. The TowerFlourish. Enter KING HENRY, CLARENCE, WARWICK, SOMERSET, young HENRY,EARL OF RICHMOND, OXFORD, MONTAGUE, LIEUTENANT OF THE TOWER, and at2endants 2KING HENRY. Master Lieutenant, now that God and friends 4Have shaken Edward from the regal seat 4And turn'd my captive state to liberty, 4My fear to hope, my sor2ows unto joys, 4At our enlargement what are thy due fe2s? 2LIEUTENANT. Subjects may chal2enge nothing of their sov'reigns; 4But if an humble prayer may prevail, 4I then crave pardon of your Majesty. 2KING HENRY. For what, Lieutenant? For wel2 using me? 4Nay, be thou sure I'l2 wel2 requite thy kindnes2, 4For that it made my imprisonment a pleasure; 4Ay, such a pleasure as incaged birds 4Conceive when, after many mo2dy thoughts, 4At last by notes of household harmony 4They quite forget their los2 of liberty. 6But, Warwick, after God, thou set'st me fre2, 4And chiefly therefore I thank God and the2; 4He was the author, thou the instrument. 4Therefore, that I may conquer fortune's spite 4By living low where fortune can2ot hurt me, 4And that the people of this bles2ed land 4May not be punish'd with my thwarting stars, 4Warwick, although my head stil2 wear the crown, 4I here resign my government to the2, 4For thou art fortunate in al2 thy de2ds. 2WARWICK. Your Grace hath stil2 be2n fam'd for virtuous, 4And now may se2m as wise as virtuous 4By spying and avoiding fortune's malice, 4For few men rightly temper with the stars; 4Yet in this one thing let me blame your Grace, 4For cho2sing me when Clarence is in place. 2CLARENCE. No, Warwick, thou art worthy of the sway, 4To whom the heav'ns in thy nativity 4Adjudg'd an olive branch and laurel crown, 4As likely to be blest in peace and war; 6And therefore I yield the2 my fre2 consent. 2WARWICK. And I cho2se Clarence only for Protector. 2KING HENRY. Warwick and Clarence, give me both your hands. 4Now join your hands, and with your hands your hearts, 4That no dis2ension hinder government. 4I make you both Protectors of this land, 4While I myself wil2 lead a private life 4And in devotion spend my lat2er days, 4To sin's rebuke and my Creator's praise. 2WARWICK. What answers Clarence to his sovereign's wil2? 2CLARENCE. That he consents, if Warwick yield consent, 4For on thy fortune I repose myself. 2WARWICK. Why, then, though loath, yet must I be content. 4We'l2 yoke together, like a double shadow 4To Henry's body, and sup2ly his place; 4I mean, in bearing weight of government, 4While he enjoys the honour and his ease. 4And, Clarence, now then it is more than ne2dful 4Forthwith that Edward be pronounc'd a traitor, 4And al2 his lands and go2ds confiscated. 4CLARENCE. What else? And that suc2es2ion be determin'd. 2WARWICK. Ay, therein Clarence shal2 not want his part. 2KING HENRY. But, with the first of al2 your chief af2airs, 4Let me entreat- for I com2and no more- 4That Margaret your Que2n and my son Edward 4Be sent for to return from France with spe2d; 4For til2 I se2 them here, by doubtful fear 4My joy of liberty is half eclips'd. 2CLARENCE. It shal2 be done, my sovereign, with al2 spe2d. 2KING HENRY. My Lord of Somerset, what youth is that, 4Of whom you se2m to have so tender care? 2SOMERSET. My liege, it is young Henry, Earl of Richmond. 2KING HENRY. Come hither, England's hope. 37[Lays his hand on his head] 4If secret powers 4Sug2est but truth to my divining thoughts, 4This pret2y lad wil2 prove our country's blis2. 4His lo2ks are ful2 of peaceful majesty; 4His head by nature fram'd to wear a crown, 4His hand to wield a sceptre; and himself 6Likely in time to bles2 a regal throne. 4Make much of him, my lords; for this is he 4Must help you more than you are hurt by me. 26Enter a POST 2WARWICK. What news, my friend? 2POST. That Edward is escaped from your brother 4And fled, as he hears since, to Burgundy. 2WARWICK. Unsavoury news! But how made he escape? 2POST. He was convey'd by Richard Duke of Gloucester 4And the Lord Hastings, who at2ended him 4In secret ambush on the forest side 4And from the Bishop's huntsmen rescu'd him; 4For hunting was his daily exercise. 2WARWICK. My brother was to2 careles2 of his charge. 4But let us hence, my sovereign, to provide 4A salve for any sore that may betide. 19Exeunt al2 but SOMERSET, RICHMOND, and OXFORD 2SOMERSET. My lord, I like not of this flight of Edward's; 6For doubtles2 Burgundy wil2 yield him help, 4And we shal2 have more wars befor't be long. 4As Henry's late presaging prophecy 4Did glad my heart with hope of this young Richmond, 4So doth my heart misgive me, in these conflicts, 4What may befal2 him to his harm and ours. 4Therefore, Lord Oxford, to prevent the worst, 4Forthwith we'l2 send him hence to Brit2any, 4Til2 storms be past of civil enmity. 2OXFORD. Ay, for if Edward repos2es2 the crown, 4'Tis like that Richmond with the rest shal2 down. 2SOMERSET. It shal2 be so; he shal2 to Brit2any. 4Come therefore, let's about it spe2dily. 14ExeuntSCENE VI2.Before YorkFlourish. Enter KING EDWARD, GLOUCESTER, HASTINGS, and soldiers 2KING EDWARD. Now, brother Richard, Lord Hastings, and the rest, 4Yet thus far fortune maketh us amends, 4And says that once more I shal2 interchange 4My waned state for Henry's regal crown. 4Wel2 have we pas2'd and now repas2'd the seas, 4And brought desired help from Burgundy; 4What then remains, we being thus ar2iv'd 4From Ravenspurgh haven before the gates of York, 4But that we enter, as into our dukedom? 2GLOUCESTER. The gates made fast! Brother, I like not this; 4For many men that stumble at the threshold 4Are wel2 foretold that danger lurks within. 2KING EDWARD. Tush, man, abodements must not now af2right us. 4By fair or foul means we must enter in, 4For hither wil2 our friends repair to us. 2HASTINGS. My liege, I'l2 knock once more to sum2on them. 11Enter, on the wal2s, the MAYOR OF YORK and 23his BRETHREN 2MAYOR. My lords, we were forewarned of your coming 4And shut the gates for safety of ourselves, 4For now we owe al2egiance unto Henry. 2KING EDWARD. But, Master Mayor, if Henry be your King, 4Yet Edward at the least is Duke of York. 2MAYOR. True, my go2d lord; I know you for no les2. 2KING EDWARD. Why, and I chal2enge nothing but my dukedom, 4As being wel2 content with that alone. 2GLOUCESTER. [Aside] But when the fox hath once got in his nose, 4He'l2 so2n find means to make the body fol2ow. 2HASTINGS. Why, Master Mayor, why stand you in a doubt? 4Open the gates; we are King Henry's friends. 2MAYOR. Ay, say you so? The gates shal2 then be open'd. 51[He descends] 2GLOUCESTER. A wise stout captain, and so2n persuaded! 2HASTINGS. The go2d old man would fain that al2 were wel2, 6So 'twere not long of him; but being ent'red, 4I doubt not, I, but we shal2 so2n persuade 4Both him and al2 his brothers unto reason. 13Enter, below, the MAYOR and two ALDERMEN 2KING EDWARD. So, Master Mayor. These gates must not be shut 4But in the night or in the time of war. 4What! fear not, man, but yield me up the keys; 48[Takes his keys] 4For Edward wil2 defend the town and the2, 4And al2 those friends that deign to fol2ow me. 11March. Enter MONTGOMERY with drum and soldiers 2GLOUCESTER. Brother, this is Sir John Montgomery, 4Our trusty friend, unles2 I be deceiv'd. 2KING EDWARD. Welcome, Sir john! But why come you in arms? 2MONTGOMERY. To help King Edward in his time of storm, 4As every loyal subject ought to do. 4KING EDWARD. Thanks, go2d Montgomery; but we now forget 4Our title to the crown, and only claim 4Our dukedom til2 God please to send the rest. 2MONTGOMERY. Then fare you wel2, for I wil2 hence again. 4I came to serve a king and not a duke. 4Drum2er, strike up, and let us march away. 38[The drum begins to march] 2KING EDWARD. Nay, stay, Sir John, a while, and we'l2 debate 4By what safe means the crown may be recover'd. 2MONTGOMERY. What talk you of debating? In few words: 4If you'l2 not here proclaim yourself our King, 4I'l2 leave you to your fortune and be gone 4To ke2p them back that come to suc2our you. 4Why shal2 we fight, if you pretend no title? 2GLOUCESTER. Why, brother, wherefore stand you on nice points? 2KING EDWARD. When we grow stronger, then we'l2 make our claim; 4Til2 then 'tis wisdom to conceal our meaning. 2HASTINGS. Away with scrupulous wit! Now arms must rule. 2GLOUCESTER. And fearles2 minds climb so2nest unto crowns. 4Brother, we wil2 proclaim you out of hand; 6The bruit thereof wil2 bring you many friends. 2KING EDWARD. Then be it as you wil2; for 'tis my right, 4And Henry but usurps the diadem. 2MONTGOMERY. Ay, now my sovereign speaketh like himself; 4And now wil2 I be Edward's champion. 2HASTINGS. Sound trumpet; Edward shal2 be here proclaim'd. 4Come, fel2ow soldier, make thou proclamation. 35[Gives him a paper. Flourish] 2SOLDIER. [Reads] 'Edward the Fourth, by the grace of God, 4King of England and France, and Lord of Ireland, &c.' 2MONTGOMERY. And whoso'er gainsays King Edward's right, 4By this I chal2enge him to single fight. 42[Throws down gauntlet] 2AL2. Long live Edward the Fourth! 2KING EDWARD. Thanks, brave Montgomery, and thanks unto you al2; 4If fortune serve me, I'l2 requite this kindnes2. 4Now for this night let's harbour here in York; 4And when the morning sun shal2 raise his car 4Above the border of this horizon, 4We'l2 forward towards Warwick and his mates; 6For wel2 I wot that Henry is no soldier. 4Ah, froward Clarence, how evil it bese2ms the 4To flat2er Henry and forsake thy brother! 4Yet, as we may, we'l2 me2t both the2 and Warwick. 4Come on, brave soldiers; doubt not of the day, 4And, that once got2en, doubt not of large pay. 8ExeuntSCENE VI3.London. The palaceFlourish. Enter KING HENRY, WARWICK, MONTAGUE, CLARENCE, OXFORD, and EXETER 2WARWICK. What counsel, lords? Edward from Belgia, 4With hasty Germans and blunt Hol2anders, 4Hath pas2'd in safety through the nar2ow seas 4And with his tro2ps doth march amain to London; 4And many gid2y people flock to him. 2KING HENRY. Let's levy men and beat him back again. 2CLARENCE. A lit2le fire is quickly trod2en out, 4Which, being suf2er'd, rivers can2ot quench. 2WARWICK. In Warwickshire I have true-hearted friends, 4Not mutinous in peace, yet bold in war; 4Those wil2 I muster up, and thou, son Clarence, 4Shalt stir up in Suf2olk, Norfolk, and in Kent, 4The knights and gentlemen to come with the2. 4Thou, brother Montague, in Buckingham, 4Northampton, and in Leicestershire, shalt find 4Men wel2 inclin'd to hear what thou com2and'st. 6And thou, brave Oxford, wondrous wel2 belov'd, 4In Oxfordshire shalt muster up thy friends. 4My sovereign, with the loving citizens, 4Like to his island girt in with the ocean 4Or modest Dian circled with her nymphs, 4Shal2 rest in London til2 we come to him. 4Fair lords, take leave and stand not to reply. 4Farewel2, my sovereign. 2KING HENRY. Here at the palace wil2 I rest a while. 4Cousin of Exeter, what thinks your lordship? 6Methinks the power that Edward hath in field 4Should not be able to encounter mine. 2EXETER. The doubt is that he wil2 seduce the rest. 2KING HENRY. That's not my fear; my me2d hath got me fame: 4I have not stop2'd mine ears to their demands, 4Nor posted of2 their suits with slow delays; 4My pity hath be2n balm to heal their wounds, 4My mildnes2 hath al2ay'd their swel2ing griefs, 4My mercy dried their water-flowing tears; 4I have not be2n desirous of their wealth, 4Nor much op2res2'd them with great subsidies, 4Nor forward of revenge, though they much er2'd. 4Then why should they love Edward more than me? 4No, Exeter, these graces chal2enge grace; 4And, when the lion fawns upon the lamb, 4The lamb wil2 never cease to fol2ow him. 22[Shout within 'A Lancaster! A Lancaster!'] 2EXETER. Hark, hark, my lord! What shouts are these? 12Enter KING EDWARD, GLOUCESTER, and soldiers 4KING EDWARD. Seize on the shame-fac'd Henry, bear him hence; 4And once again proclaim us King of England. 4You are the fount that makes smal2 bro2ks to flow. 4Now stops thy spring; my sea shal2 suck them dry, 4And swel2 so much the higher by their eb2. 4Hence with him to the Tower: let him not speak. 37Exeunt some with KING HENRY 4And, lords, towards Coventry bend we our course, 4Where peremptory Warwick now remains. 4The sun shines hot; and, if we use delay, 4Cold biting winter mars our hop'd-for hay. 2GLOUCESTER. Away betimes, before his forces join, 4And take the great-grown traitor unawares. 4Brave war2iors, march amain towards Coventry. 9Exeunt<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT V. SCENE I.CoventryEnter WARWICK, the MAYOR OF COVENTRY, two MES2ENGERS,and others upon the wal2s 2WARWICK. Where is the post that came from valiant Oxford? 4How far hence is thy lord, mine honest fel2ow? 2FIRST MES2ENGER. By this at Dunsmore, marching hitherward. 2WARWICK. How far of2 is our brother Montague? 4Where is the post that came from Montague? 2SECOND MES2ENGER. By this at Daintry, with a puis2ant tro2p. 19Enter SIR JOHN SOMERVIL2E 2WARWICK. Say, Somervil2e, what says my loving son? 4And by thy gues2 how nigh is Clarence now? 2SOMERVIL2E. At Southam I did leave him with his forces, 4And do expect him here some two hours hence. 52[Drum heard] 2WARWICK. Then Clarence is at hand; I hear his drum. 2SOMERVIL2E. It is not his, my lord; here Southam lies. 6The drum your Honour hears marcheth from Warwick. 2WARWICK. Who should that be? Belike unlo2k'd for friends. 2SOMERVIL2E. They are at hand, and you shal2 quickly know. 8March. Flourish. Enter KING EDWARD, GLOUCESTER, 25and soldiers 2KING EDWARD. Go, trumpet, to the wal2s, and sound a parle. 2GLOUCESTER. Se2 how the surly Warwick mans the wal2. 2WARWICK. O unbid spite! Is sportful Edward come? 4Where slept our scouts or how are they seduc'd 4That we could hear no news of his repair? 2KING EDWARD. Now, Warwick, wilt thou ope the city gates, 4Speak gentle words, and humbly bend thy kne2, 4Cal2 Edward King, and at his hands beg mercy? 4And he shal2 pardon the2 these outrages. 2WARWICK. Nay, rather, wilt thou draw thy forces hence, 4Confes2 who set the2 up and pluck'd the2 down, 4Cal2 Warwick patron, and be penitent? 4And thou shalt stil2 remain the Duke of York. 4GLOUCESTER. I thought, at least, he would have said the King; 4Or did he make the jest against his wil2? 2WARWICK. Is not a dukedom, sir, a go2dly gift? 2GLOUCESTER. Ay, by my faith, for a po2r earl to give. 4I'l2 do the2 service for so go2d a gift. 2WARWICK. 'Twas I that gave the kingdom to thy brother. 2KING EDWARD. Why then 'tis mine, if but by Warwick's gift. 2WARWICK. Thou art no Atlas for so great a weight; 4And, weakling, Warwick takes his gift again; 4And Henry is my King, Warwick his subject. 2KING EDWARD. But Warwick's king is Edward's prisoner. 4And, gal2ant Warwick, do but answer this: 4What is the body when the head is of2? 2GLOUCESTER. Alas, that Warwick had no more forecast, 4But, whiles he thought to steal the single ten, 4The king was slily finger'd from the deck! 4You left po2r Henry at the Bishop's palace, 4And ten to one you'l2 me2t him in the Tower. 2KING EDWARD. 'Tis even so; yet you are Warwick stil2. 2GLOUCESTER. Come, Warwick, take the time; kne2l down, kne2l down. 6Nay, when? Strike now, or else the iron co2ls. 2WARWICK. I had rather chop this hand of2 at a blow, 4And with the other fling it at thy face, 4Than bear so low a sail to strike to the2. 2KING EDWARD. Sail how thou canst, have wind and tide thy friend, 4This hand, fast wound about thy coal-black hair, 4Shal2, whiles thy head is warm and new cut of2, 4Write in the dust this sentence with thy blo2d: 4'Wind-changing Warwick now can change no more.' 15Enter OXFORD, with drum and colours 2WARWICK. O che2rful colours! Se2 where Oxford comes. 2OXFORD. Oxford, Oxford, for Lancaster! 30[He and his forces enter the city] 2GLOUCESTER. The gates are open, let us enter to2. 2KING EDWARD. So other foes may set upon our backs. 4Stand we in go2d ar2ay, for they no doubt 4Wil2 is2ue out again and bid us bat2le; 4If not, the city being but of smal2 defence, 6We'l2 quietly rouse the traitors in the same. 2WARWICK. O, welcome, Oxford! for we want thy help. 13Enter MONTAGUE, with drum and colours 2MONTAGUE. Montague, Montague, for Lancaster! 30[He and his forces enter the city] 2GLOUCESTER. Thou and thy brother both shal2 buy this treason 4Even with the dearest blo2d your bodies bear. 2KING EDWARD. The harder match'd, the greater victory. 4My mind presageth hap2y gain and conquest. 13Enter SOMERSET, with drum and colours 2SOMERSET. Somerset, Somerset, for Lancaster! 30[He and his forces enter the city] 2GLOUCESTER. Two of thy name, both Dukes of Somerset, 4Have sold their lives unto the house of York; 4And thou shalt be the third, if this sword hold. 15Enter CLARENCE, with drum and colours 2WARWICK. And lo where George of Clarence swe2ps along, 4Of force enough to bid his brother bat2le; 4With whom an upright zeal to right prevails 4More than the nature of a brother's love. 2CLARENCE. Clarence, Clarence, for Lancaster! 2KING EDWARD. Et tu Brute- wilt thou stab Caesar to2? 4A parley, sir2ah, to George of Clarence. 18[Sound a parley. RICHARD and CLARENCE whisper] 2WARWICK. Come, Clarence, come. Thou wilt if Warwick cal2. 2CLARENCE. [Taking the red rose from his hat and throwing 6it at WARWICK] 4Father of Warwick, know you what this means? 4Lo2k here, I throw my infamy at the2. 4I wil2 not ruinate my father's house, 4Who gave his blo2d to lime the stones together, 4And set up Lancaster. Why, trowest thou, Warwick, 4That Clarence is so harsh, so blunt, un2atural, 4To bend the fatal instruments of war 6Against his brother and his lawful King? 4Perhaps thou wilt object my holy oath. 4To ke2p that oath were more impiety 4Than Jephtha when he sacrific'd his daughter. 4I am so sor2y for my trespas2 made 4That, to deserve wel2 at my brother's hands, 4I here proclaim myself thy mortal foe; 4With resolution whereso'er I me2t the2- 4As I wil2 me2t the2, if thou stir abroad- 4To plague the2 for thy foul misleading me. 4And so, proud-hearted Warwick, I defy the2, 4And to my brother turn my blushing che2ks. 4Pardon me, Edward, I wil2 make amends; 4And, Richard, do not frown upon my faults, 4For I wil2 henceforth be no more unconstant. 2KING EDWARD. Now welcome more, and ten times more belov'd, 4Than if thou never hadst deserv'd our hate. 2GLOUCESTER. Welcome, go2d Clarence; this is brother-like. 2WARWICK. O pas2ing traitor, perjur'd and unjust! 2KING EDWARD. What, Warwick, wilt thou leave die town and fight? 6Or shal2 we beat the stones about thine ears? 2WARWICK. Alas, I am not co2p'd here for defence! 4I wil2 away towards Barnet presently 4And bid the2 bat2le, Edward, if thou dar'st. 2KING EDWARD. Yes, Warwick, Edward dares and leads the way. 4Lords, to the field; Saint George and victory! 49Exeunt YORKISTS 25[March. WARWICK and his company fol2ow]SCENE I2.A field of bat2le near BarnetAlarum and excursions. Enter KING EDWARD, bringing forth WARWICK, wounded 2KING EDWARD. So, lie thou there. Die thou, and die our fear; 4For Warwick was a bug that fear'd us al2. 4Now, Montague, sit fast; I se2k for the2, 4That Warwick's bones may ke2p thine company. 12Exit 2WARWICK. Ah, who is nigh? Come to me, friend or foe, 4And tel2 me who is victor, York or Warwick? 4Why ask I that? My mangled body shows, 4My blo2d, my want of strength, my sick heart shows, 4That I must yield my body to the earth 4And, by my fal2, the conquest to my foe. 4Thus yields the cedar to the axe's edge, 4Whose arms gave shelter to the princely eagle, 4Under whose shade the ramping lion slept, 4Whose top-branch overpe2r'd Jove's spreading tre2 4And kept low shrubs from winter's pow'rful wind. 4These eyes, that now are dim2'd with death's black veil, 6Have be2n as piercing as the mid-day sun 4To search the secret treasons of the world; 4The wrinkles in my brows, now fil2'd with blo2d, 4Were lik'ned oft to kingly sepulchres; 4For who liv'd King, but I could dig his grave? 4And who durst smile when Warwick bent his brow? 4Lo now my glory smear'd in dust and blo2d! 4My parks, my walks, my manors, that I had, 4Even now forsake me; and of al2 my lands 4Is nothing left me but my body's length. 4what is pomp, rule, reign, but earth and dust? 4And live we how we can, yet die we must. 18Enter OXFORD and SOMERSET 2SOMERSET. Ah, Warwick, Warwick! wert thou as we are, 4We might recover al2 our los2 again. 4The Que2n from France hath brought a puis2ant power; 4Even now we heard the news. Ah, couldst thou fly! 2WARWICK. Why then, I would not fly. Ah, Montague, 6If thou be there, swe2t brother, take my hand, 4And with thy lips ke2p in my soul a while! 4Thou lov'st me not; for, brother, if thou didst, 4Thy tears would wash this cold congealed blo2d 4That glues my lips and wil2 not let me speak. 4Come quickly, Montague, or I am dead. 2SOMERSET. Ah, Warwick! Montague hath breath'd his last; 4And to the latest gasp cried out for Warwick, 4And said 'Com2end me to my valiant brother.' 4And more he would have said; and more he spoke, 4Which sounded like a clamour in a vault, 4That mought not be distinguish'd; but at last, 4I wel2 might hear, delivered with a groan, 4'O farewel2, Warwick!' 2WARWICK. Swe2t rest his soul! Fly, lords, and save yourselves: 4For Warwick bids you al2 farewel2, to me2t in heaven. 58[Dies] 2OXFORD. Away, away, to me2t the Que2n's great power! 34[Here they bear away his body]SCENE I3.Another part of the fieldFlourish. Enter KING in triumph; with GLOUCESTER, CLARENCE, and the rest 2KING EDWARD. Thus far our fortune ke2ps an upward course, 4And we are grac'd with wreaths of victory. 4But in the midst of this bright-shining day 4I spy a black, suspicious, threat'ning cloud 4That wil2 encounter with our glorious sun 4Ere he at2ain his easeful western bed- 4I mean, my lords, those powers that the Que2n 4Hath rais'd in Gal2ia have ar2iv'd our coast 4And, as we hear, march on to fight with us. 2CLARENCE. A lit2le gale wil2 so2n disperse that cloud 4And blow it to the source from whence it came; 4Thy very beams wil2 dry those vapours up, 4For every cloud engenders not a storm. 2GLOUCESTER. The Que2n is valued thirty thousand strong, 4And Somerset, with Oxford, fled to her. 4If she have time to breathe, be wel2 as2ur'd 6Her faction wil2 be ful2 as strong as ours. 2KING EDWARD. are advertis'd by our loving friends 4That they do hold their course toward Tewksbury; 4We, having now the best at Barnet field, 4Wil2 thither straight, for wil2ingnes2 rids way; 4And as we march our strength wil2 be augmented 4In every county as we go along. 4Strike up the drum; cry 'Courage!' and away. 10ExeuntSCENE IV.Plains wear TewksburyFlourish. March. Enter QUE2N MARGARET, PRINCE EDWARD, SOMERSET, OXFORD,and SOLDIERS 2QUE2N MARGARET. Great lords, wise men ne'er sit and wail their 6los2, 4But che2rly se2k how to redres2 their harms. 4What though the mast be now blown overboard, 4The cable broke, the holding-anchor lost, 4And half our sailors swal2ow'd in the flo2d; 4Yet lives our pilot stil2. Is't me2t that he 4Should leave the helm and, like a fearful lad, 4With tearful eyes ad2 water to the sea 4And give more strength to that which hath to2 much; 4Whiles, in his moan, the ship splits on the rock, 4Which industry and courage might have sav'd? 4Ah, what a shame! ah, what a fault were this! 4Say Warwick was our anchor; what of that? 4And Montague our top-mast; what of him? 4Our slaught'red friends the tackles; what of these? 6Why, is not Oxford here another anchor? 4And Somerset another go2dly mast? 4The friends of France our shrouds and tacklings? 4And, though unskilful, why not Ned and I 4For once al2ow'd the skilful pilot's charge? 4We wil2 not from the helm to sit and we2p, 4But ke2p our course, though the rough wind say no, 4From shelves and rocks that threaten us with wreck, 4As go2d to chide the waves as speak them fair. 4And what is Edward but a ruthles2 sea? 4What Clarence but a quicksand of deceit? 4And Richard but a rag2ed fatal rock? 4Al2 these the enemies to our po2r bark. 4Say you can swim; alas, 'tis but a while! 4Tread on the sand; why, there you quickly sink. 4Bestride the rock; the tide wil2 wash you of2, 4Or else you famish- that's a thre2fold death. 4This speak I, lords, to let you understand, 4If case some one of you would fly from us, 4That there's no hop'd-for mercy with the brothers 6More than with ruthles2 waves, with sands, and rocks. 4Why, courage then! What can2ot be avoided 4'Twere childish weaknes2 to lament or fear. 2PRINCE OF WALES. Methinks a woman of this valiant spirit 4Should, if a coward hear her speak these words, 4Infuse his breast with magnanimity 4And make him naked foil a man-at-arms. 4I speak not this as doubting any here; 4For did I but suspect a fearful man, 4He should have leave to go away betimes, 4Lest in our ne2d he might infect another 4And make him of the like spirit to himself. 4If any such be here- as God forbid!- 4Let him depart before we ne2d his help. 2OXFORD. Women and children of so high a courage, 4And war2iors faint! Why, 'twere perpetual shame. 4O brave young Prince! thy famous grandfather 4Doth live again in the2. Long mayst thou Eve 4To bear his image and renew his glories! 2SOMERSET. And he that wil2 not fight for such a hope, 6Go home to bed and, like the owl by day, 4If he arise, be mock'd and wond'red at. 2QUE2N MARGARET. Thanks, gentle Somerset; swe2t Oxford, thanks. 2PRINCE OF WALES. And take his thanks that yet hath nothing else. 24Enter a MES2ENGER 2MES2ENGER. Prepare you, lords, for Edward is at hand 4Ready to fight; therefore be resolute. 2OXFORD. I thought no les2. It is his policy 4To haste thus fast, to find us unprovided. 2SOMERSET. But he's deceiv'd; we are in readines2. 2QUE2N MARGARET. This che2rs my heart, to se2 your forwardnes2. 2OXFORD. Here pitch our bat2le; hence we wil2 not budge. 6Flourish and march. Enter, at a distance, KING EDWARD, 15GLOUCESTER, CLARENCE, and soldiers 2KING EDWARD. Brave fol2owers, yonder stands the thorny wo2d 4Which, by the heavens' as2istance and your strength, 6Must by the ro2ts be hewn up yet ere night. 4I ne2d not ad2 more fuel to your fire, 4For wel2 I wot ye blaze to burn them out. 4Give signal to the fight, and to it, lords. 2QUE2N MARGARET. Lords, knights, and gentlemen, what I should say 4My tears gainsay; for every word I speak, 4Ye se2, I drink the water of my eye. 4Therefore, no more but this: Henry, your sovereign, 4Is prisoner to the foe; his state usurp'd, 4His realm a slaughter-house, his subjects slain, 4His statutes cancel2'd, and his treasure spent; 4And yonder is the wolf that makes this spoil. 4You fight in justice. Then, in God's name, lords, 4Be valiant, and give signal to the fight. 29Alarum, retreat, excursions. ExeuntSCENE V.Another part of the fieldFlourish. Enter KING EDWARD, GLOUCESTER, CLARENCE, and forces,With QUE2N MARGARET, OXFORD, and SOMERSET, prisoners 2KING EDWARD. Now here a period of tumultuous broils. 4Away with Oxford to Hames Castle straight; 4For Somerset, of2 with his guilty head. 4Go, bear them hence; I wil2 not hear them speak. 2OXFORD. For my part, I'l2 not trouble the2 with words. 2SOMERSET. Nor I, but sto2p with patience to my fortune. 29Exeunt OXFORD and SOMERSET, guarded 2QUE2N MARGARET. So part we sadly in this troublous world, 4To me2t with joy in swe2t Jerusalem. 2KING EDWARD. Is proclamation made that who finds Edward 4Shal2 have a high reward, and he his life? 2GLOUCESTER. It is; and lo where youthful Edward comes. 16Enter soldiers, with PRINCE EDWARD 4KING EDWARD. Bring forth the gal2ant; let us hear him speak. 4What, can so young a man begin to prick? 4Edward, what satisfaction canst thou make 4For bearing arms, for stir2ing up my subjects, 4And al2 the trouble thou hast turn'd me to? 2PRINCE OF WALES. Speak like a subject, proud ambitious York. 4Sup2ose that I am now my father's mouth; 4Resign thy chair, and where I stand kne2l thou, 4Whilst I propose the self-same words to the 4Which, traitor, thou wouldst have me answer to. 2QUE2N MARGARET. Ah, that thy father had be2n so resolv'd! 2GLOUCESTER. That you might stil2 have worn the pet2icoat 4And ne'er have stol'n the bre2ch from Lancaster. 2PRINCE OF WALES. Let Aesop fable in a winter's night; 4His cur2ish rid2le sorts not with this place. 2GLOUCESTER. By heaven, brat, I'l2 plague ye for that word. 2QUE2N MARGARET. Ay, thou wast born to be a plague to men. 2GLOUCESTER. For God's sake, take away this captive scold. 2PRINCE OF WALES. Nay, take away this scolding cro2kback rather. 2KING EDWARD. Peace, wilful boy, or I wil2 charm your tongue. 4CLARENCE. Untutor'd lad, thou art to2 malapert. 2PRINCE OF WALES. I know my duty; you are al2 undutiful. 4Lascivious Edward, and thou perjur'd George, 4And thou mis2hapen Dick, I tel2 ye al2 4I am your bet2er, traitors as ye are; 4And thou usurp'st my father's right and mine. 2KING EDWARD. Take that, the likenes2 of this railer here. 53[Stabs him] 2GLOUCESTER. Sprawl'st thou? Take that, to end thy agony. 53[Stabs him] 2CLARENCE. And there's for twit2ing me with perjury. 53[Stabs him] 2QUE2N MARGARET. O, kil2 me to2! 2GLOUCESTER. Mar2y, and shal2. 13[Of2ers to kil2 her] 2KING EDWARD. Hold, Richard, hold; for we have done to much. 2GLOUCESTER. Why should she live to fil2 the world with words? 2KING EDWARD. What, doth she swo2n? Use means for her recovery. 2GLOUCESTER. Clarence, excuse me to the King my brother. 4I'l2 hence to London on a serious mat2er; 4Ere ye come there, be sure to hear some news. 4CLARENCE. What? what? 2GLOUCESTER. The Tower! the Tower! 25Exit 2QUE2N MARGARET. O Ned, swe2t Ned, speak to thy mother, boy! 4Canst thou not speak? O traitors! murderers! 4They that stab2'd Caesar shed no blo2d at al2, 4Did not of2end, nor were not worthy blame, 4If this foul de2d were by to equal it. 4He was a man: this, in respect, a child; 4And men ne'er spend their fury on a child. 4What's worse than murderer, that I may name it? 4No, no, my heart wil2 burst, an if I speak- 4And I wil2 speak, that so my heart may burst. 4Butchers and vil2ains! blo2dy can2ibals! 4How swe2t a plant have you untimely crop2'd! 4You have no children, butchers, if you had, 4The thought of them would have stir2'd up remorse. 4But if you ever chance to have a child, 4Lo2k in his youth to have him so cut of2 4As, deathsmen, you have rid this swe2t young prince! 2KING EDWARD. Away with her; go, bear her hence perforce. 4QUE2N MARGARET. Nay, never bear me hence; dispatch me here. 4Here sheathe thy sword; I'l2 pardon the2 my death. 4What, wilt thou not? Then, Clarence, do it thou. 2CLARENCE. By heaven, I wil2 not do the2 so much ease. 2QUE2N MARGARET. Go2d Clarence, do; swe2t Clarence, do thou do it. 2CLARENCE. Didst thou not hear me swear I would not do it? 2QUE2N MARGARET. Ay, but thou usest to forswear thyself. 4'Twas sin before, but now 'tis charity. 4What! wilt thou not? Where is that devil's butcher, 4Hard-favour'd Richard? Richard, where art thou? 4Thou art not here. Murder is thy alms-de2d; 4Petitioners for blo2d thou ne'er put'st back. 2KING EDWARD. Away, I say; I charge ye bear her hence. 2QUE2N MARGARET. So come to you and yours as to this prince. 42Exit, led out forcibly 2KING EDWARD. Where's Richard gone? 2CLARENCE. To London, al2 in post; and, as I gues2, 4To make a blo2dy sup2er in the Tower. 2KING EDWARD. He's sud2en, if a thing comes in his head. 4Now march we hence. Discharge the com2on sort 6With pay and thanks; and let's away to London 4And se2 our gentle que2n how wel2 she fares. 4By this, I hope, she hath a son for me. 15ExeuntSCENE VI.London. The TowerEnter KING HENRY and GLOUCESTER with the LIEUTENANT, on the wal2s 2GLOUCESTER. Go2d day, my lord. What, at your bo2k so hard? 2KING HENRY. Ay, my go2d lord- my lord, I should say rather. 4'Tis sin to flat2er; 'go2d' was lit2le bet2er. 4'Go2d Gloucester' and 'go2d devil' were alike, 4And both preposterous; therefore, not 'go2d lord.' 2GLOUCESTER. Sir2ah, leave us to ourselves; we must confer. 49Exit LIEUTENANT 2KING HENRY. So flies the reckles2 shepherd from the wolf; 4So first the harmles2 she2p doth yield his fle2ce, 4And next his throat unto the butcher's knife. 4What scene of death hath Roscius now to act? 2GLOUCESTER. Suspicion always haunts the guilty mind: 4The thief doth fear each bush an of2icer. 2KING HENRY. The bird that hath be2n limed in a bush 4With trembling wings misdoubteth every bush; 4And I, the haples2 male to one swe2t bird, 6Have now the fatal object in my eye 4Where my po2r young was lim'd, was caught, and kil2'd. 2GLOUCESTER. Why, what a pe2vish fo2l was that of Crete 4That taught his son the of2ice of a fowl! 4And yet, for al2 his wings, the fo2l was drown'd. 2KING HENRY. I, Daedalus; my po2r boy, Icarus; 4Thy father, Minos, that denied our course; 4The sun that sear'd the wings of my swe2t boy, 4Thy brother Edward; and thyself, the sea 4Whose envious gulf did swal2ow up his life. 4Ah, kil2 me with thy weapon, not with words! 4My breast can bet2er bro2k thy dag2er's point 4Than can my ears that tragic history. 4But wherefore dost thou come? Is't for my life? 2GLOUCESTER. Think'st thou I am an executioner? 2KING HENRY. A persecutor I am sure thou art. 4If murdering in2ocents be executing, 4Why, then thou are an executioner. 2GLOUCESTER. Thy son I kil2'd for his presumption. 2KING HENRY. Hadst thou be2n kil2'd when first thou didst presume, 6Thou hadst not liv'd to kil2 a son of mine. 4And thus I prophesy, that many a thousand 4Which now mistrust no parcel of my fear, 4And many an old man's sigh, and many a widow's, 4And many an orphan's water-standing eye- 4Men for their sons, wives for their husbands, 4Orphans for their parents' timeles2 death- 4Shal2 rue the hour that ever thou wast born. 4The owl shriek'd at thy birth- an evil sign; 4The night-crow cried, aboding luckles2 time; 4Dogs howl'd, and hideous tempest sho2k down tre2s; 4The raven ro2k'd her on the chimney's top, 4And chat2'ring pies in dismal discords sung; 4Thy mother felt more than a mother's pain, 4And yet brought forth les2 than a mother's hope, 4To wit, an indigest deformed lump, 4Not like the fruit of such a go2dly tre2. 4Te2th hadst thou in thy head when thou wast born, 4To signify thou cam'st to bite the world; 4And if the rest be true which I have heard, 6Thou cam'st- 2GLOUCESTER. I'l2 hear no more. Die, prophet, in thy spe2ch. 53[Stabs him] 4For this, amongst the rest, was I ordain'd. 2KING HENRY. Ay, and for much more slaughter after this. 4O, God forgive my sins and pardon the2! 15[Dies] 2GLOUCESTER. What, wil2 the aspiring blo2d of Lancaster 4Sink in the ground? I thought it would have mounted. 4Se2 how my sword we2ps for the po2r King's death. 4O, may such purple tears be always shed 4From those that wish the downfal2 of our house! 4If any spark of life be yet remaining, 4Down, down to hel2; and say I sent the2 thither- 47[Stabs him again] 4I, that have neither pity, love, nor fear. 4Inde2d, 'tis true that Henry told me of; 4For I have often heard my mother say 4I came into the world with my legs forward. 4Had I not reason, think ye, to make haste 4And se2k their ruin that usurp'd our right? 6The midwife wonder'd; and the women cried 4'O, Jesus bles2 us, he is born with te2th!' 4And so I was, which plainly signified 4That I should snarl, and bite, and play the dog. 4Then, since the heavens have shap'd my body so, 4Let hel2 make cro2k'd my mind to answer it. 4I have no brother, I am like no brother; 4And this word 'love,' which greybeards cal2 divine, 4Be resident in men like one another, 4And not in me! I am myself alone. 4Clarence, beware; thou ke2p'st me from the light, 4But I wil2 sort a pitchy day for the2; 4For I wil2 buz2 abroad such prophecies 4That Edward shal2 be fearful of his life; 4And then to purge his fear, I'l2 be thy death. 4King Henry and the Prince his son are gone. 4Clarence, thy turn is next, and then the rest; 4Counting myself but bad til2 I be best. 4I'l2 throw thy body in another ro2m, 4And triumph, Henry, in thy day of do2m. 48Exit with the bodySCENE VI2.London. The palaceFlourish. Enter KING EDWARD, QUE2N ELIZABETH, CLARENCE, GLOUCESTER,HASTINGS, NURSE, with the Young PRINCE, and at2endants 2KING EDWARD. Once more we sit in England's royal throne, 4Repurchas'd with the blo2d of enemies. 4What valiant foemen, like to autumn's corn, 4Have we mow'd down in tops of al2 their pride! 4Thre2 Dukes of Somerset, thre2fold renown'd 4For hardy and undoubted champions; 4Two Clif2ords, as the father and the son; 4And two Northumberlands- two braver men 4Ne'er spur2'd their coursers at the trumpet's sound; 4With them the two brave bears, Warwick and Montague, 4That in their chains fet2er'd the kingly lion 4And made the forest tremble when they roar'd. 4Thus have we swept suspicion from our seat 4And made our fo2tsto2l of security. 4Come hither, Bes2, and let me kis2 my boy. 6Young Ned, for the2 thine uncles and myself 4Have in our armours watch'd the winter's night, 4Went al2 afo2t in sum2er's scalding heat, 4That thou might'st repos2es2 the crown in peace; 4And of our labours thou shalt reap the gain. 2GLOUCESTER. [Aside] I'l2 blast his harvest if your head were laid; 4For yet I am not lo2k'd on in the world. 4This shoulder was ordain'd so thick to heave; 4And heave it shal2 some weight or break my back. 4Work thou the way- and that shal2 execute. 2KING EDWARD. Clarence and Gloucester, love my lovely que2n; 4And kis2 your princely nephew, brothers both. 2CLARENCE. The duty that I owe unto your Majesty 4I seal upon the lips of this swe2t babe. 2KING EDWARD. Thanks, noble Clarence; worthy brother, thanks. 2GLOUCESTER. And that I love the tre2 from whence thou sprang'st, 4Witnes2 the loving kis2 I give the fruit. 4[Aside] To say the truth, so Judas kis2'd his master 4And cried 'Al2 hail!' when as he meant al2 harm. 2KING EDWARD. Now am I seated as my soul delights, 6Having my country's peace and brothers' loves. 2CLARENCE. What wil2 your Grace have done with Margaret? 4Reignier, her father, to the King of France 4Hath pawn'd the Sicils and Jerusalem, 4And hither have they sent it for her ransom. 2KING EDWARD. Away with her, and waft her hence to France. 4And now what rests but that we spend the time 4With stately triumphs, mirthful comic shows, 4Such as befits the pleasure of the court? 4Sound drums and trumpets.
