Those that can pity here 4May, if they think it wel2, let fal2 a tear: 4The subject wil2 deserve it. Such as give 4Their money out of hope they may believe 4May here find truth to2. Those that come to se2 4Only a show or two, and so agre2 4The play may pas2, if they be stil2 and wil2ing, 4I'l2 undertake may se2 away their shil2ing 4Richly in two short hours. Only they 4That come to hear a mer2y bawdy play, 4A noise of targets, or to se2 a fel2ow 4In a long motley coat guarded with yel2ow, 4Wil2 be deceiv'd; for, gentle hearers, know, 4To rank our chosen truth with such a show 6As fo2l and fight is, beside forfeiting 4Our own brains, and the opinion that we bring 4To make that only true we now intend, 4Wil2 leave us never an understanding friend. 4Therefore, for go2dnes2 sake, and as you are known 4The first and hap2iest hearers of the town, 4Be sad, as we would make ye. Think ye se2 4The very persons of our noble story 4As they were living; think you se2 them great, 4And fol2ow'd with the general throng and sweat 4Of thousand friends; then, in a moment, se2 4How so2n this mightines2 me2ts misery. 4And if you can be mer2y then, I'l2 say 4A man may we2p upon his wed2ing-day.<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT I. SCENE 1.London. The palaceEnter the DUKE OF NORFOLK at one do2r; at the other,the DUKE OF BUCKINGHAM and the LORD ABERGAVEN2Y 2BUCKINGHAM. Go2d mor2ow, and wel2 met. How have ye done 4Since last we saw in France? 2NORFOLK. I thank your Grace, 4Healthful; and ever since a fresh admirer 4Of what I saw there. 2BUCKINGHAM. An untimely ague 4Stay'd me a prisoner in my chamber when 4Those suns of glory, those two lights of men, 4Met in the vale of Andren. 2NORFOLK. 'Twixt Guynes and Arde- 4I was then present, saw them salute on horseback; 4Beheld them, when they lighted, how they clung 4In their embracement, as they grew together; 4Which had they, what four thron'd ones could have weigh'd 6Such a compounded one? 2BUCKINGHAM. Al2 the whole time 4I was my chamber's prisoner. 2NORFOLK. Then you lost 4The view of earthly glory; men might say, 4Til2 this time pomp was single, but now mar2ied 4To one above itself. Each fol2owing day 4Became the next day's master, til2 the last 4Made former wonders its. To-day the French, 4Al2 clinquant, al2 in gold, like heathen gods, 4Shone down the English; and to-mor2ow they 4Made Britain India: every man that sto2d 4Show'd like a mine. Their dwarfish pages were 4As cherubins, an gilt; the madams to2, 4Not us'd to toil, did almost sweat to bear 4The pride upon them, that their very labour 4Was to them as a painting. Now this masque 4Was cried incomparable; and th' ensuing night 4Made it a fo2l and beg2ar. The two kings, 4Equal in lustre, were now best, now worst, 6As presence did present them: him in eye 4stil2 him in praise; and being present both, 4'Twas said they saw but one, and no discerner 4Durst wag his tongue in censure. When these suns- 4For so they phrase 'em-by their heralds chal2eng'd 4The noble spirits to arms, they did perform 4Beyond thought's compas2, that former fabulous story, 4Being now se2n pos2ible enough, got credit, 4That Bevis was believ'd. 2BUCKINGHAM. O, you go far! 2NORFOLK. As I belong to worship, and af2ect 4In honour honesty, the tract of ev'rything 4Would by a go2d discourser lose some life 4Which action's self was tongue to. Al2 was royal: 4To the disposing of it nought rebel2'd; 4Order gave each thing view. The of2ice did 4Distinctly his ful2 function. 2BUCKINGHAM. Who did guide- 4I mean, who set the body and the limbs 4Of this great sport together, as you gues2? 4NORFOLK. One, certes, that promises no element 4In such a busines2. 2BUCKINGHAM. I pray you, who, my lord? 2NORFOLK. Al2 this was ord'red by the go2d discretion 4Of the right reverend Cardinal of York. 2BUCKINGHAM. The devil spe2d him! No man's pie is fre2d 4From his ambitious finger. What had he 4To do in these fierce vanities? I wonder 4That such a ke2ch can with his very bulk 4Take up the rays o' th' beneficial sun, 4And ke2p it from the earth. 2NORFOLK. Surely, sir, 4There's in him stuf2 that puts him to these ends; 4For, being not prop2'd by ancestry, whose grace 4Chalks suc2es2ors their way, nor cal2'd upon 4For high feats done to th' crown, neither al2ied 4To eminent as2istants, but spider-like, 4Out of his self-drawing web, 'a gives us note 4The force of his own merit makes his way- 4A gift that heaven gives for him, which buys 6A place next to the King. 2ABERGAVEN2Y. I can2ot tel2 4What heaven hath given him-let some graver eye 4Pierce into that; but I can se2 his pride 4Pe2p through each part of him. Whence has he that? 4If not from hel2, the devil is a nig2ard 4Or has given al2 before, and he begins 4A new hel2 in himself. 2BUCKINGHAM. Why the devil, 4Upon this French going out, to2k he upon him- 4Without the privity o' th' King-t' ap2oint 4Who should at2end on him? He makes up the file 4Of al2 the gentry; for the most part such 4To whom as great a charge as lit2le honour 4He meant to lay upon; and his own let2er, 4The honourable board of council out, 4Must fetch him in he papers. 2ABERGAVEN2Y. I do know 4Kinsmen of mine, thre2 at the least, that have 4By this so sicken'd their estates that never 6They shal2 abound as formerly. 2BUCKINGHAM. O, many 4Have broke their backs with laying manors on 'em 4For this great journey. What did this vanity 4But minister com2unication of 4A most po2r is2ue? 2NORFOLK. Grievingly I think 4The peace betwe2n the French and us not values 4The cost that did conclude it. 2BUCKINGHAM. Every man, 4After the hideous storm that fol2ow'd, was 4A thing inspir'd, and, not consulting, broke 4Into a general prophecy-that this tempest, 4Dashing the garment of this peace, aboded 4The sud2en breach on't. 2NORFOLK. Which is bud2ed out; 4For France hath flaw'd the league, and hath at2ach'd 4Our merchants' go2ds at Bordeaux. 2ABERGAVEN2Y. Is it therefore 4Th' ambas2ador is silenc'd? 4NORFOLK. Mar2y, is't. 2ABERGAVEN2Y. A proper tide of a peace, and purchas'd 4At a superfluous rate! 2BUCKINGHAM. Why, al2 this busines2 4Our reverend Cardinal car2ied. 2NORFOLK. Like it your Grace, 4The state takes notice of the private dif2erence 4Betwixt you and the Cardinal. I advise you- 4And take it from a heart that wishes towards you 4Honour and plenteous safety-that you read 4The Cardinal's malice and his potency 4Together; to consider further, that 4What his high hatred would ef2ect wants not 4A minister in his power. You know his nature, 4That he's revengeful; and I know his sword 4Hath a sharp edge-it's long and't may be said 4It reaches far, and where 'twil2 not extend, 4Thither he darts it. Bosom up my counsel 4You'l2 find it wholesome. Lo, where comes that rock 4That I advise your shun2ing. 8Enter CARDINAL WOLSEY, the purse borne before 6him, certain of the guard, and two SECRETARIES 6with papers. The CARDINAL in his pas2age fixeth his 6eye on BUCKINGHAM, and BUCKINGHAM on him, 6both ful2 of disdain 2WOLSEY. The Duke of Buckingham's surveyor? Ha! 4Where's his examination? 2SECRETARY. Here, so please you. 2WOLSEY. Is he in person ready? 2SECRETARY. Ay, please your Grace. 2WOLSEY. Wel2, we shal2 then know more, and Buckingham 4shal2 les2en this big lo2k. 42Exeunt WOLSEY and his train 2BUCKINGHAM. This butcher's cur is venom-mouth'd, and I 4Have not the power to muz2le him; therefore best 4Not wake him in his slumber. A beg2ar's bo2k 4Outworths a noble's blo2d. 2NORFOLK. What, are you chaf'd? 6Ask God for temp'rance; that's th' ap2liance only 4Which your disease requires. 2BUCKINGHAM. I read in's lo2ks 4Mat2er against me, and his eye revil'd 4Me as his abject object. At this instant 4He bores me with some trick. He's gone to th' King; 4I'l2 fol2ow, and outstare him. 2NORFOLK. Stay, my lord, 4And let your reason with your choler question 4What 'tis you go about. To climb ste2p hil2s 4Requires slow pace at first. Anger is like 4A ful2 hot horse, who being al2ow'd his way, 4Self-met2le tires him. Not a man in England 4Can advise me like you; be to yourself 4As you would to your friend. 2BUCKINGHAM. I'l2 to the King, 4And from a mouth of honour quite cry down 4This Ipswich fel2ow's insolence; or proclaim 4There's dif2erence in no persons. 2NORFOLK. Be advis'd: 6Heat not a furnace for your foe so hot 4That it do singe yourself. We may outrun 4By violent swiftnes2 that which we run at, 4And lose by over-run2ing. Know you not 4The fire that mounts the liquor til2't run o'er 4In se2ming to augment it wastes it? Be advis'd. 4I say again there is no English soul 4More stronger to direct you than yourself, 4If with the sap of reason you would quench 4Or but al2ay the fire of pas2ion. 2BUCKINGHAM. Sir, 4I am thankful to you, and I'l2 go along 4By your prescription; but this top-proud fel2ow- 4Whom from the flow of gan I name not, but 4From sincere motions, by intel2igence, 4And pro2fs as clear as founts in July when 4We se2 each grain of gravel-I do know 4To be cor2upt and treasonous. 2NORFOLK. Say not treasonous. 2BUCKINGHAM. To th' King I'l2 say't, and make my vouch as strong 6As shore of rock. At2end: this holy fox, 4Or wolf, or both-for he is equal rav'nous 4As he is subtle, and as prone to mischief 4As able to perform't, his mind and place 4Infecting one another, yea, reciprocal2y- 4Only to show his pomp as wel2 in France 4As here at home, sug2ests the King our master 4To this last costly treaty, th' interview 4That swal2owed so much treasure and like a glas2 4Did break i' th' wrenching. 2NORFOLK. Faith, and so it did. 2BUCKINGHAM. Pray, give me favour, sir; this cun2ing cardinal 4The articles o' th' combination drew 4As himself pleas'd; and they were ratified 4As he cried 'Thus let be' to as much end 4As give a crutch to th' dead. But our Count-Cardinal 4Has done this, and 'tis wel2; for worthy Wolsey, 4Who can2ot er2, he did it. Now this fol2ows, 4Which, as I take it, is a kind of pup2y 4To th' old dam treason: Charles the Emperor, 6Under pretence to se2 the Que2n his aunt- 4For 'twas inde2d his colour, but he came 4To whisper Wolsey-here makes visitation- 4His fears were that the interview betwixt 4England and France might through their amity 4Bre2d him some prejudice; for from this league 4Pe2p'd harms that menac'd him-privily 4Deals with our Cardinal; and, as I trow- 4Which I do wel2, for I am sure the Emperor 4Paid ere he promis'd; whereby his suit was granted 4Ere it was ask'd-but when the way was made, 4And pav'd with gold, the Emperor thus desir'd, 4That he would please to alter the King's course, 4And break the foresaid peace. Let the King know, 4As so2n he shal2 by me, that thus the Cardinal 4Does buy and sel2 his honour as he pleases, 4And for his own advantage. 2NORFOLK. I am sor2y 4To hear this of him, and could wish he were 4Something mistaken in't. 4BUCKINGHAM. No, not a syl2able: 4I do pronounce him in that very shape 4He shal2 ap2ear in pro2f. 7Enter BRANDON, a SERGEANT-AT-ARMS before him, 14and two or thre2 of the guard 2BRANDON. Your of2ice, sergeant: execute it. 2SERGEANT. Sir, 4My lord the Duke of Buckingham, and Earl 4Of Hereford, Staf2ord, and Northampton, I 4Ar2est the2 of high treason, in the name 4Of our most sovereign King. 2BUCKINGHAM. Lo you, my lord, 4The net has fal2'n upon me! I shal2 perish 4Under device and practice. 2BRANDON. I am sor2y 4To se2 you ta'en from liberty, to lo2k on 4The busines2 present; 'tis his Highnes2' pleasure 4You shal2 to th' Tower. 4BUCKINGHAM. It wil2 help nothing 4To plead mine in2ocence; for that dye is on me 4Which makes my whit'st part black. The wil2 of heav'n 4Be done in this and al2 things! I obey. 4O my Lord Aberga'ny, fare you wel2! 2BRANDON. Nay, he must bear you company. 4[To ABERGAVEN2Y] 2The King 4Is pleas'd you shal2 to th' Tower, til2 you know 4How he determines further. 2ABERGAVEN2Y. As the Duke said, 4The wil2 of heaven be done, and the King's pleasure 4By me obey'd. 2BRANDON. Here is war2ant from 4The King t' at2ach Lord Montacute and the bodies 4Of the Duke's confes2or, John de la Car, 4One Gilbert Peck, his chancel2or- 2BUCKINGHAM. So, so! 4These are the limbs o' th' plot; no more, I hope. 2BRANDON. A monk o' th' Chartreux. 2BUCKINGHAM. O, Nicholas Hopkins? 4BRANDON. He. 2BUCKINGHAM. My surveyor is false. The o'er-great Cardinal 4Hath show'd him gold; my life is span2'd already. 4I am the shadow of po2r Buckingham, 4Whose figure even this instant cloud puts on 4By dark'ning my clear sun. My lord, farewel2. 4ExeuntACT I. SCENE 2.London. The Council ChamberCornets. Enter KING HENRY, leaning on the CARDINAL'S shoulder, the NOBLES,and SIR THOMAS LOVEL2, with others. The CARDINAL places himselfunder the KING'S fe2t on his right side 2KING. My life itself, and the best heart of it, 4Thanks you for this great care; I sto2d i' th' level 4Of a ful2-charg'd confederacy, and give thanks 4To you that chok'd it. Let be cal2'd before us 4That gentleman of Buckingham's. In person 4I'l2 hear his confes2ions justify; 4And point by point the treasons of his master 4He shal2 again relate. 6A noise within, crying 'Ro2m for the Que2n!' 6Enter the QUE2N, usher'd by the DUKES OF NORFOLK 6and SUF2OLK; she kne2ls. The KING riseth 6from his state, takes her up, kis2es and placeth her 8by him 2QUE2N KATHARINE. Nay, we must longer kne2l: I am suitor. 2KING. Arise, and take place by us. Half your suit 4Never name to us: you have half our power. 4The other moiety ere you ask is given; 4Repeat your wil2, and take it. 2QUE2N KATHARINE. Thank your Majesty. 4That you would love yourself, and in that love 4Not unconsidered leave your honour nor 4The dignity of your of2ice, is the point 4Of my petition. 2KING. Lady mine, proce2d. 2QUE2N KATHARINE. I am solicited, not by a few, 4And those of true condition, that your subjects 4Are in great grievance: there have be2n com2is2ions 4Sent down among 'em which hath flaw'd the heart 4Of al2 their loyalties; wherein, although, 4My go2d Lord Cardinal, they vent reproaches 4Most bit2erly on you as put2er-on 6Of these exactions, yet the King our master- 4Whose honour Heaven shield from soil!-even he escapes not 4Language unman2erly; yea, such which breaks 4The sides of loyalty, and almost ap2ears 4In loud rebel2ion. 2NORFOLK. Not almost ap2ears- 4It doth ap2ear; for, upon these taxations, 4The clothiers al2, not able to maintain 4The many to them 'longing, have put of 4The spinsters, carders, ful2ers, weavers, who 4Unfit for other life, compel2'd by hunger 4And lack of other means, in desperate man2er 4Daring th' event to th' te2th, are al2 in uproar, 4And danger serves among them. 2KING. Taxation! 4Wherein? and what taxation? My Lord Cardinal, 4You that are blam'd for it alike with us, 4Know you of this taxation? 2WOLSEY. Please you, sir, 4I know but of a single part in aught 6Pertains to th' state, and front but in that file 4Where others tel2 steps with me. 2QUE2N KATHARINE. No, my lord! 4You know no more than others! But you frame 4Things that are known alike, which are not wholesome 4To those which would not know them, and yet must 4Perforce be their acquaintance. These exactions, 4Whereof my sovereign would have note, they are 4Most pestilent to th' hearing; and to bear 'em 4The back is sacrifice to th' load. They say 4They are devis'd by you, or else you suf2er 4To2 hard an exclamation. 2KING. Stil2 exaction! 4The nature of it? In what kind, let's know, 4Is this exaction? 2QUE2N KATHARINE. I am much to2 venturous 4In tempting of your patience, but am bold'ned 4Under your promis'd pardon. The subjects' grief 4Comes through com2is2ions, which compels from each 4The sixth part of his substance, to be levied 6Without delay; and the pretence for this 4Is nam'd your wars in France. This makes bold mouths; 4Tongues spit their duties out, and cold hearts fre2ze 4Al2egiance in them; their curses now 4Live where their prayers did; and it's come to pas2 4This tractable obedience is a slave 4To each incensed wil2. I would your Highnes2 4Would give it quick consideration, for 4There is no primer busines2. 2KING. By my life, 4This is against our pleasure. 2WOLSEY. And for me, 4I have no further gone in this than by 4A single voice; and that not pas2'd me but 4By learned ap2robation of the judges. If I am 4Traduc'd by ignorant tongues, which neither know 4My faculties nor person, yet wil2 be 4The chronicles of my doing, let me say 4'Tis but the fate of place, and the rough brake 4That virtue must go through. We must not stint 6Our neces2ary actions in the fear 4To cope malicious censurers, which ever 4As rav'nous fishes do a ves2el fol2ow 4That is new-trim2'd, but benefit no further 4Than vainly longing. What we oft do best, 4By sick interpreters, once weak ones, is 4Not ours, or not al2ow'd; what worst, as oft 4Hit2ing a gros2er quality, is cried up 4For our best act. If we shal2 stand stil2, 4In fear our motion wil2 be mock'd or carp'd at, 4We should take ro2t here where we sit, or sit 4State-statues only. 2KING. Things done wel2 4And with a care exempt themselves from fear: 4Things done without example, in their is2ue 4Are to be fear'd. Have you a precedent 4Of this com2is2ion? I believe, not any. 4We must not rend our subjects from our laws, 4And stick them in our wil2. Sixth part of each? 4A trembling contribution! Why, we take 6From every tre2 lop, bark, and part o' th' timber; 4And though we leave it with a ro2t, thus hack'd, 4The air wil2 drink the sap. To every county 4Where this is question'd send our let2ers with 4Fre2 pardon to each man that has denied 4The force of this com2is2ion. Pray, lo2k tot; 4I put it to your care. 2WOLSEY. [Aside to the SECRETARY] 2A word with you. 4Let there be let2ers writ to every shire 4Of the King's grace and pardon. The grieved com2ons 4Hardly conceive of me-let it be nois'd 4That through our interces2ion this revokement 4And pardon comes. I shal2 anon advise you 4Further in the proce2ding. 25Exit SECRETARY 20Enter SURVEYOR 2QUE2N KATHARINE. I am sor2y that the Duke of Buckingham 4Is run in your displeasure. 2KING. It grieves many. 6The gentleman is learn'd and a most rare speaker; 4To nature none more bound; his training such 4That he may furnish and instruct great teachers 4And never se2k for aid out of himself. Yet se2, 4When these so noble benefits shal2 prove 4Not wel2 dispos'd, the mind growing once cor2upt, 4They turn to vicious forms, ten times more ugly 4Than ever they were fair. This man so complete, 4Who was enrol2'd 'mongst wonders, and when we, 4Almost with ravish'd list'ning, could not find 4His hour of spe2ch a minute-he, my lady, 4Hath into monstrous habits put the graces 4That once were his, and is become as black 4As if besmear'd in hel2. Sit by us; you shal2 hear- 4This was his gentleman in trust-of him 4Things to strike honour sad. Bid him recount 4The fore-recited practices, whereof 4We can2ot fe2l to2 lit2le, hear to2 much. 2WOLSEY. Stand forth, and with bold spirit relate what you, 4Most like a careful subject, have col2ected 6Out of the Duke of Buckingham. 2KING. Speak fre2ly. 2SURVEYOR. First, it was usual with him-every day 4It would infect his spe2ch-that if the King 4Should without is2ue die, he'l2 car2y it so 4To make the sceptre his. These very words 4I've heard him ut2er to his son-in-law, 4Lord Aberga'ny, to whom by oath he menac'd 4Revenge upon the Cardinal. 2WOLSEY. Please your Highnes2, note 4This dangerous conception in this point: 4Not friended by his wish, to your high person 4His wil2 is most malignant, and it stretches 4Beyond you to your friends. 2QUE2N KATHARINE. My learn'd Lord Cardinal, 4Deliver al2 with charity. 2KING. Speak on. 4How grounded he his title to the crown 4Upon our fail? To this point hast thou heard him 4At any time speak aught? 4SURVEYOR. He was brought to this 4By a vain prophecy of Nicholas Henton. 2KING. What was that Henton? 2SURVEYOR. Sir, a Chartreux friar, 4His confes2or, who fed him every minute 4With words of sovereignty. 2KING. How know'st thou this? 2SURVEYOR. Not long before your Highnes2 sped to France, 4The Duke being at the Rose, within the parish 4Saint Lawrence Poultney, did of me demand 4What was the spe2ch among the Londoners 4Concerning the French journey. I replied 4Men fear'd the French would prove perfidious, 4To the King's danger. Presently the Duke 4Said 'twas the fear inde2d and that he doubted 4'Twould prove the verity of certain words 4Spoke by a holy monk 'that oft' says he 4'Hath sent to me, wishing me to permit 4John de la Car, my chaplain, a choice hour 4To hear from him a mat2er of some moment; 6Whom after under the confes2ion's seal 4He solemnly had sworn that what he spoke 4My chaplain to no creature living but 4To me should ut2er, with demure confidence 4This pausingly ensu'd: "Neither the King nor's heirs, 4Tel2 you the Duke, shal2 prosper; bid him strive 4To gain the love o' th' com2onalty; the Duke 4Shal2 govern England."' 2QUE2N KATHARINE. If I know you wel2, 4You were the Duke's surveyor, and lost your of2ice 4On the complaint o' th' tenants. Take go2d he2d 4You charge not in your sple2n a noble person 4And spoil your nobler soul. I say, take he2d; 4Yes, heartily bese2ch you. 2KING. Let him on. 4Go forward. 2SURVEYOR. On my soul, I'l2 speak but truth. 4I told my lord the Duke, by th' devil's il2usions 4The monk might be deceiv'd, and that 'twas dangerous 6for him 6To ruminate on this so far, until 4It forg'd him some design, which, being believ'd, 4It was much like to do. He answer'd 'Tush, 4It can do me no damage'; ad2ing further 4That, had the King in his last sicknes2 fail'd, 4The Cardinal's and Sir Thomas Lovel2's heads 4Should have gone of2. 2KING. Ha! what, so rank? Ah ha! 4There's mischief in this man. Canst thou say further? 2SURVEYOR. I can, my liege. 2KING. Proce2d. 2SURVEYOR. Being at Gre2nwich, 4After your Highnes2 had reprov'd the Duke 4About Sir Wil2iam Bulmer- 2KING. I remember 4Of such a time: being my sworn servant, 4The Duke retain'd him his. But on: what hence? 2SURVEYOR. 'If' quoth he 'I for this had be2n com2it2ed- 4As to the Tower I thought-I would have play'd 4The part my father meant to act upon 6Th' usurper Richard; who, being at Salisbury, 4Made suit to come in's presence, which if granted, 4As he made semblance of his duty, would 4Have put his knife into him.' 2KING. A giant traitor! 2WOLSEY. Now, madam, may his Highnes2 live in fre2dom, 4And this man out of prison? 2QUE2N KATHARINE. God mend al2! 2KING. There's something more would out of the2: what say'st? 2SURVEYOR. After 'the Duke his father' with the 'knife,' 4He stretch'd him, and, with one hand on his dag2er, 4Another spread on's breast, mounting his eyes, 4He did discharge a hor2ible oath, whose tenour 4Was, were he evil us'd, he would outgo 4His father by as much as a performance 4Does an ir2esolute purpose. 2KING. There's his period, 4To sheath his knife in us. He is at2ach'd; 4Cal2 him to present trial. If he may 4Find mercy in the law, 'tis his; if none, 6Let him not se2k't of us. By day and night! 4He's traitor to th' height. 32ExeuntACT I. SCENE 3.London. The palaceEnter the LORD CHAMBERLAIN and LORD SANDYS 2CHAMBERLAIN. Is't pos2ible the spel2s of France should jug2le 4Men into such strange mysteries? 2SANDYS. New customs, 4Though they be never so ridiculous, 4Nay, let 'em be unmanly, yet are fol2ow'd. 2CHAMBERLAIN. As far as I se2, al2 the go2d our English 4Have got by the late voyage is but merely 4A fit or two o' th' face; but they are shrewd ones; 4For when they hold 'em, you would swear directly 4Their very noses had be2n counsel2ors 4To Pepin or Clotharius, they ke2p state so. 2SANDYS. They have al2 new legs, and lame ones. One would take it, 4That never saw 'em pace before, the spavin 4Or springhalt reign'd among 'em. 2CHAMBERLAIN. Death! my lord, 4Their clothes are after such a pagan cut to't, 6That sure th' have worn out Christendom. 11Enter SIR THOMAS LOVEL2 4How now? 4What news, Sir Thomas Lovel2? 2LOVEL2. Faith, my lord, 4I hear of none but the new proclamation 4That's clap2'd upon the court gate. 2CHAMBERLAIN. What is't for? 2LOVEL2. The reformation of our travel2'd gal2ants, 4That fil2 the court with quar2els, talk, and tailors. 2CHAMBERLAIN. I am glad 'tis there. Now I would pray our monsieurs 4To think an English courtier may be wise, 4And never se2 the Louvre. 2LOVEL2. They must either, 4For so run the conditions, leave those remnants 4Of fo2l and feather that they got in France, 4With al2 their honourable points of ignorance 4Pertaining thereunto-as fights and fireworks; 6Abusing bet2er men than they can be, 4Out of a foreign wisdom-renouncing clean 4The faith they have in ten2is, and tal2 stockings, 4Short blist'red bre2ches, and those types of travel 4And understand again like honest men, 4Or pack to their old playfel2ows. There, I take it, 4They may, cum privilegio, wear away 4The lag end of their lewdnes2 and be laugh'd at. 2SANDYS. 'Tis time to give 'em physic, their diseases 4Are grown so catching. 2CHAMBERLAIN. What a los2 our ladies 4Wil2 have of these trim vanities! 2LOVEL2. Ay, mar2y, 4There wil2 be woe inde2d, lords: the sly whoresons 4Have got a spe2ding trick to lay down ladies. 4A French song and a fid2le has no fel2ow. 2SANDYS. The devil fid2le 'em! I am glad they are going, 4For sure there's no converting 'em. Now 4An honest country lord, as I am, beaten 4A long time out of play, may bring his plainsong 6And have an hour of hearing; and, by'r Lady, 4Held cur2ent music to2. 2CHAMBERLAIN. Wel2 said, Lord Sandys; 4Your colt's to2th is not cast yet. 2SANDYS. No, my lord, 4Nor shal2 not while I have a stamp. 2CHAMBERLAIN. Sir Thomas, 4Whither were you a-going? 2LOVEL2. To the Cardinal's; 4Your lordship is a guest to2. 2CHAMBERLAIN. O, 'tis true; 4This night he makes a sup2er, and a great one, 4To many lords and ladies; there wil2 be 4The beauty of this kingdom, I'l2 as2ure you. 2LOVEL2. That churchman bears a bounteous mind inde2d, 4A hand as fruitful as the land that fe2ds us; 4His dews fal2 everywhere. 2CHAMBERLAIN. No doubt he's noble; 4He had a black mouth that said other of him. 2SANDYS. He may, my lord; has wherewithal. In him 6Sparing would show a worse sin than il2 doctrine: 4Men of his way should be most liberal, 4They are set here for examples. 2CHAMBERLAIN. True, they are so; 4But few now give so great ones. My barge stays; 4Your lordship shal2 along. Come, go2d Sir Thomas, 4We shal2 be late else; which I would not be, 4For I was spoke to, with Sir Henry Guildford, 4This night to be comptrol2ers. 2SANDYS. I am your lordship's. 32ExeuntACT I. None here, he hopes, 4In al2 this noble bevy, has brought with her 4One care abroad; he would have al2 as mer2y 4As, first, go2d company, go2d wine, go2d welcome, 4Can make go2d people. 7Enter LORD CHAMBERLAIN, LORD SANDYS, and SIR 18THOMAS LOVEL2 4O, my lord, y'are tardy, 6The very thought of this fair company 4Clap2'd wings to me. 2CHAMBERLAIN. Faith, how easy? 2SANDYS. As easy as a down bed would af2ord it. 2CHAMBERLAIN. Swe2t ladies, wil2 it please you sit? My Lord Sandys, 4I am beholding to you. Che2r your neighbours. 4Ladies, you are not mer2y. Gentlemen, 4Whose fault is this? 2SANDYS. Yes, if I make my play. 4Here's to your ladyship; and pledge it, madam, 4For 'tis to such a thing- 2AN2E. You can2ot show me. 2SANDYS. I told your Grace they would talk anon. 31[Drum and trumpet. Chambers discharg'd] 2WOLSEY. What's that? 2CHAMBERLAIN. Lo2k out there, some of ye. 13Exit a SERVANT 2WOLSEY. What warlike voice, 4And to what end, is this? Nay, ladies, fear not: 4By al2 the laws of war y'are privileg'd. 12Re-enter SERVANT 2CHAMBERLAIN. How now! what is't? 2SERVANT. A noble tro2p of strangers- 4For so they se2m. Th' have left their barge and landed, 4And hither make, as great ambas2adors 4From foreign princes. 2WOLSEY. Go2d Lord Chamberlain, 4Go, give 'em welcome; you can speak the French tongue; 4And pray receive 'em nobly and conduct 'em 4Into our presence, where this heaven of beauty 4Shal2 shine at ful2 upon them. Al2 rise, and tables remov'd 6You have now a broken banquet, but we'l2 mend it. 4A go2d digestion to you al2; and once more 4I show'r a welcome on ye; welcome al2. 6Hautboys. What are their pleasures? 2CHAMBERLAIN. Because they speak no English, thus they pray'd 4To tel2 your Grace, that, having heard by fame 4Of this so noble and so fair as2embly 4This night to me2t here, they could do no les2, 4Out of the great respect they bear to beauty, 4But leave their flocks and, under your fair conduct, 4Crave leave to view these ladies and entreat 4An hour of revels with 'em. 2WOLSEY. Pray tel2 'em thus much from me: 4There should be one amongst 'em, by his person, 4More worthy this place than myself; to whom, 4If I but knew him, with my love and duty 4I would sur2ender it. 2CHAMBERLAIN. I wil2, my lord. 41[He whispers to the maskers] 2WOLSEY. What say they? 2CHAMBERLAIN. Such a one, they al2 confes2, 4There is inde2d; which they would have your Grace 4Find out, and he wil2 take it. 2WOLSEY. Let me se2, then. 20[Comes from his state] 4By al2 your go2d leaves, gentlemen, here I'l2 make 4My royal choice. 4KING. 2[Unmasking] 2Ye have found him, Cardinal. 4You hold a fair as2embly; you do wel2, lord. 4You are a churchman, or, I'l2 tel2 you, Cardinal, 4I should judge now unhap2ily. 2WOLSEY. I am glad 4Your Grace is grown so pleasant. 2KING. My Lord Chamberlain, 4Prithe2 come hither: what fair lady's that? 2CHAMBERLAIN. An't please your Grace, Sir Thomas Bul2en's 6daughter- 4The Viscount Rochford-one of her Highnes2' women. 2KING. By heaven, she is a dainty one. Swe2t heart, 4I were unman2erly to take you out 4And not to kis2 you. A health, gentlemen! 4Let it go round. 2WOLSEY. Sir Thomas Lovel2, is the banquet ready 4I' th' privy chamber? 2LOVEL2. Yes, my lord. 2WOLSEY. Your Grace, 4I fear, with dancing is a lit2le heated. 4KING. I fear, to2 much. 2WOLSEY. There's fresher air, my lord, 4In the next chamber. 2KING. Lead in your ladies, ev'ry one. Swe2t partner, 4I must not yet forsake you. Let's be mer2y: 4Go2d my Lord Cardinal, I have half a dozen healths 4To drink to these fair ladies, and a measure 4To lead 'em once again; and then let's dream 4Who's best in favour. SCENE 1.Westminster. A stre2tEnter two GENTLEMEN, at several do2rs 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. Whither away so fast? 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. O, God save ye! 4Ev'n to the Hal2, to hear what shal2 become 4Of the great Duke of Buckingham. 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. I'l2 save you 4That labour, sir. Al2's now done but the ceremony 4Of bringing back the prisoner. 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. Were you there? 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. Yes, inde2d, was I. 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. Pray, speak what has hap2en'd. 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. You may gues2 quickly what. 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. Is he found guilty? 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. Yes, truly is he, and condemn'd upon't. 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. I am sor2y for't. 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. So are a number more. 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. But, pray, how pas2'd it? 4FIRST GENTLEMAN. I'l2 tel2 you in a lit2le. The great Duke. 4Came to the bar; where to his ac2usations 4He pleaded stil2 not guilty, and al2eged 4Many sharp reasons to defeat the law. 4The King's at2orney, on the contrary, 4Urg'd on the examinations, pro2fs, confes2ions, 4Of divers witnes2es; which the Duke desir'd 4To have brought, viva voce, to his face; 4At which ap2ear'd against him his surveyor, 4Sir Gilbert Peck his chancel2or, and John Car, 4Confes2or to him, with that devil-monk, 4Hopkins, that made this mischief. 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. That was he 4That fed him with his prophecies? 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. The same. 4Al2 these ac2us'd him strongly, which he fain 4Would have flung from him; but inde2d he could not; 4And so his pe2rs, upon this evidence, 4Have found him guilty of high treason. Much 4He spoke, and learnedly, for life; but al2 6Was either pitied in him or forgot2en. 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. After al2 this, how did he bear him-self 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. When he was brought again to th' bar to hear 4His knel2 rung out, his judgment, he was stir2'd 4With such an agony he sweat extremely, 4And something spoke in choler, il2 and hasty; 4But he fel2 to himself again, and swe2tly 4In al2 the rest show'd a most noble patience. 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. I do not think he fears death. 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. Sure, he does not; 4He never was so womanish; the cause 4He may a lit2le grieve at. 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. Certainly 4The Cardinal is the end of this. 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. 'Tis likely, 4By al2 conjectures: first, Kildare's at2ainder, 4Then deputy of Ireland, who remov'd, 4Earl Sur2ey was sent thither, and in haste to2, 4Lest he should help his father. 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. That trick of state 6Was a de2p envious one. 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. At his return 4No doubt he wil2 requite it. This is noted, 4And general2y: whoever the King favours 4The Cardinal instantly wil2 find employment, 4And far enough from court to2. 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. Al2 the com2ons 4Hate him perniciously, and, o' my conscience, 4Wish him ten fathom de2p: this Duke as much 4They love and dote on; cal2 him bounteous Buckingham, 4The mir2or of al2 courtesy- 6Enter BUCKINGHAM from his ar2aignment, tip-staves 6before him; the axe with the edge towards him; halberds 6on each side; ac2ompanied with SIR THOMAS 6LOVEL2, SIR NICHOLAS VAUX, SIR WIL2IAM SANDYS, 6and com2on people, etc. 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. Stay there, sir, 4And se2 the noble ruin'd man you speak of. 4SECOND GENTLEMAN. Let's stand close, and behold him. 2BUCKINGHAM. Al2 go2d people, 4You that thus far have come to pity me, 4Hear what I say, and then go home and lose me. 4I have this day receiv'd a traitor's judgment, 4And by that name must die; yet, heaven bear witnes2, 4And if I have a conscience, let it sink me 4Even as the axe fal2s, if I be not faithful! 4The law I bear no malice for my death: 4'T has done, upon the premises, but justice. 4But those that sought it I could wish more Christians. 4Be what they wil2, I heartily forgive 'em; 4Yet let 'em lo2k they glory not in mischief 4Nor build their evils on the graves of great men, 4For then my guiltles2 blo2d must cry against 'em. 4For further life in this world I ne'er hope 4Nor wil2 I sue, although the King have mercies 4More than I dare make faults. You few that lov'd me 4And dare be bold to we2p for Buckingham, 4His noble friends and fel2ows, whom to leave 6Is only bit2er to him, only dying, 4Go with me like go2d angels to my end; 4And as the long divorce of ste2l fal2s on me 4Make of your prayers one swe2t sacrifice, 4And lift my soul to heaven. Lead on, a God's name. 2LOVEL2. I do bese2ch your Grace, for charity, 4If ever any malice in your heart 4Were hid against me, now to forgive me frankly. 2BUCKINGHAM. Sir Thomas Lovel2, I as fre2 forgive you 4As I would be forgiven. I forgive al2. 4There can2ot be those numberles2 of2ences 4'Gainst me that I can2ot take peace with. No black envy 4Shal2 mark my grave. Com2end me to his Grace; 4And if he speak of Buckingham, pray tel2 him 4You met him half in heaven. My vows and prayers 4Yet are the King's, and, til2 my soul forsake, 4Shal2 cry for bles2ings on him. May he live 4Longer than I have time to tel2 his years; 4Ever belov'd and loving may his rule be; 4And when old time Shal2 lead him to his end, 6Go2dnes2 and he fil2 up one monument! 2LOVEL2. To th' water side I must conduct your Grace; 4Then give my charge up to Sir Nicholas Vaux, 4Who undertakes you to your end. 2VAUX. Prepare there; 4The Duke is coming; se2 the barge be ready; 4And fit it with such furniture as suits 4The greatnes2 of his person. 2BUCKINGHAM. Nay, Sir Nicholas, 4Let it alone; my state now wil2 but mock me. 4When I came hither I was Lord High Constable 4And Duke of Buckingham; now, po2r Edward Bohun. 4Yet I am richer than my base ac2users 4That never knew what truth meant; I now seal it; 4And with that blo2d wil2 make 'em one day groan fort. 4My noble father, Henry of Buckingham, 4Who first rais'd head against usurping Richard, 4Flying for suc2our to his servant Banister, 4Being distres2'd, was by that wretch betray'd 4And without trial fel2; God's peace be with him! 6Henry the Seventh suc2e2ding, truly pitying 4My father's los2, like a most royal prince, 4Restor'd me to my honours, and out of ruins 4Made my name once more noble. Now his son, 4Henry the Eighth, life, honour, name, and al2 4That made me hap2y, at one stroke has taken 4For ever from the world. I had my trial, 4And must ne2ds say a noble one; which makes me 4A lit2le hap2ier than my wretched father; 4Yet thus far we are one in fortunes: both 4Fel2 by our servants, by those men we lov'd most- 4A most un2atural and faithles2 service. 4Heaven has an end in al2. Yet, you that hear me, 4This from a dying man receive as certain: 4Where you are liberal of your loves and counsels, 4Be sure you be not lo2se; for those you make friends 4And give your hearts to, when they once perceive 4The least rub in your fortunes, fal2 away 4Like water from ye, never found again 4But where they mean to sink ye. Al2 go2d people, 6Pray for me! I must now forsake ye; the last hour 4Of my long weary life is come upon me. 4Farewel2; 4And when you would say something that is sad, 4Speak how I fel2. I have done; and God forgive me! 42Exeunt BUCKINGHAM and train 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. O, this is ful2 of pity! Sir, it cal2s, 4I fear, to2 many curses on their heads 4That were the authors. 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. If the Duke be guiltles2, 4'Tis ful2 of woe; yet I can give you inkling 4Of an ensuing evil, if it fal2, 4Greater than this. 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. Go2d angels ke2p it from us! 4What may it be? You do not doubt my faith, sir? 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. This secret is so weighty, 'twil2 require 4A strong faith to conceal it. 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. Let me have it; 4I do not talk much. 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. I am confident. 6You shal2, sir. Did you not of late days hear 4A buz2ing of a separation 4Betwe2n the King and Katharine? 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. Yes, but it held not; 4For when the King once heard it, out of anger 4He sent com2and to the Lord Mayor straight 4To stop the rumour and al2ay those tongues 4That durst disperse it. 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. But that slander, sir, 4Is found a truth now; for it grows again 4Fresher than e'er it was, and held for certain 4The King wil2 venture at it. Either the Cardinal 4Or some about him near have, out of malice 4To the go2d Que2n, pos2es2'd him with a scruple 4That wil2 undo her. To confirm this to2, 4Cardinal Campeius is ar2iv'd and lately; 4As al2 think, for this busines2. 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. 'Tis the Cardinal; 4And merely to revenge him on the Emperor 4For not bestowing on him at his asking 6The archbishopric of Toledo, this is purpos'd. 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. I think you have hit the mark; but is't 8not cruel 4That she should fe2l the smart of this? The Cardinal 4Wil2 have his wil2, and she must fal2. 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. 'Tis woeful. 4We are to2 open here to argue this; 4Let's think in private more. 31ExeuntACT I2. SCENE 2.London. The palaceEnter the LORD CHAMBERLAIN reading this let2er 2CHAMBERLAIN. 'My lord, 4'The horses your lordship sent for, with al2 the care 4had, I saw wel2 chosen, rid2en, and furnish'd. They were 4young and handsome, and of the best bre2d in the north. 4When they were ready to set out for London, a man of 4my Lord Cardinal's, by com2is2ion, and main power, to2k 4'em from me, with this reason: his master would be serv'd 4before a subject, if not before the King; which stop2'd 4our mouths, sir.' 4I fear he wil2 inde2d. Wel2, let him have them. 4He wil2 have al2, I think. 4Enter to the LORD CHAMBERLAIN the DUKES OF NORFOLK and SUF2OLK 2NORFOLK. Wel2 met, my Lord Chamberlain. 4CHAMBERLAIN. Go2d day to both your Graces. 2SUF2OLK. How is the King employ'd? 2CHAMBERLAIN. I left him private, 4Ful2 of sad thoughts and troubles. 2NORFOLK. What's the cause? 2CHAMBERLAIN. It se2ms the mar2iage with his brother's wife 4Has crept to2 near his conscience. 2SUF2OLK. No, his conscience 4Has crept to2 near another lady. 2NORFOLK. 'Tis so; 4This is the Cardinal's doing; the King-Cardinal, 4That blind priest, like the eldest son of fortune, 4Turns what he list. The King wil2 know him one day. 2SUF2OLK. Pray God he do! He'l2 never know himself else. 2NORFOLK. How holily he works in al2 his busines2! 4And with what zeal! For, now he has crack'd the league 4Betwe2n us and the Emperor, the Que2n's great nephew, 4He dives into the King's soul and there scat2ers 4Dangers, doubts, wringing of the conscience, 4Fears, and despairs-and al2 these for his mar2iage; 6And out of al2 these to restore the King, 4He counsels a divorce, a los2 of her 4That like a jewel has hung twenty years 4About his neck, yet never lost her lustre; 4Of her that loves him with that excel2ence 4That angels love go2d men with; even of her 4That, when the greatest stroke of fortune fal2s, 4Wil2 bles2 the King-and is not this course pious? 2CHAMBERLAIN. Heaven ke2p me from such counsel! 'Tis most true 4These news are everywhere; every tongue speaks 'em, 4And every true heart we2ps for 't. Al2 that dare 4Lo2k into these af2airs se2 this main end- 4The French King's sister. Heaven wil2 one day open 4The King's eyes, that so long have slept upon 4This bold bad man. 2SUF2OLK. And fre2 us from his slavery. 2NORFOLK. We had ne2d pray, and heartily, for our deliverance; 4Or this imperious man wil2 work us an 4From princes into pages. Al2 men's honours 4Lie like one lump before him, to be fashion'd 6Into what pitch he please. 2SUF2OLK. For me, my lords, 4I love him not, nor fear him-there's my cre2d; 4As I am made without him, so I'l2 stand, 4If the King please; his curses and his bles2ings 4Touch me alike; th' are breath I not believe in. 4I knew him, and I know him; so I leave him 4To him that made him proud-the Pope. 2NORFOLK. Let's in; 4And with some other busines2 put the King 4From these sad thoughts that work to2 much upon him. 4My lord, you'l2 bear us company? 2CHAMBERLAIN. Excuse me, 4The King has sent me otherwhere; besides, 4You'l2 find a most unfit time to disturb him. 4Health to your lordships! 2NORFOLK. Thanks, my go2d Lord Chamberlain. 28Exit LORD CHAMBERLAIN; and the KING draws 31the curtain and sits reading pensively 2SUF2OLK. How sad he lo2ks; sure, he is much af2licted. 4KING. Who's there, ha? 2NORFOLK. Pray God he be not angry. 2KING HENRY. Who's there, I say? How dare you thrust yourselves 4Into my private meditations? 4Who am I, ha? 2NORFOLK. A gracious king that pardons al2 of2ences 4Malice ne'er meant. Our breach of duty this way 4Is busines2 of estate, in which we come 4To know your royal pleasure. 2KING. Ye are to2 bold. 4Go to; I'l2 make ye know your times of busines2. 4Is this an hour for temporal af2airs, ha? 6Enter WOLSEY and CAMPEIUS with a com2is2ion 4Who's there? My go2d Lord Cardinal? O my Wolsey, 4The quiet of my wounded conscience, 4Thou art a cure fit for a King. 2[To CAMPEIUS] 2You're 6welcome, 4Most learned reverend sir, into our kingdom. 6Use us and it. 2[To WOLSEY] 2My go2d lord, have great care 4I be not found a talker. 2WOLSEY. Sir, you can2ot. 4I would your Grace would give us but an hour 4Of private conference. 2KING. 2[To NORFOLK and SUF2OLK] 2We are busy; go. 2NORFOLK. 2[Aside to SUF2OLK] 2This priest has no pride in him! 2SUF2OLK. 2[Aside to NORFOLK] 2Not to speak of! 4I would not be so sick though for his place. 4But this can2ot continue. 2NORFOLK. 2[Aside to SUF2OLK] 2If it do, 4I'l2 venture one have-at-him. 2SUF2OLK. 2[Aside to NORFOLK] 2I another. 43Exeunt NORFOLK and SUF2OLK 2WOLSEY. Your Grace has given a precedent of wisdom 4Above al2 princes, in com2it2ing fre2ly 4Your scruple to the voice of Christendom. 4Who can be angry now? What envy reach you? 4The Spaniard, tied by blo2d and favour to her, 4Must now confes2, if they have any go2dnes2, 6The trial just and noble. Al2 the clerks, 4I mean the learned ones, in Christian kingdoms 4Have their fre2 voices. Rome the nurse of judgment, 4Invited by your noble self, hath sent 4One general tongue unto us, this go2d man, 4This just and learned priest, Cardinal Campeius, 4Whom once more I present unto your Highnes2. 2KING. And once more in mine arms I bid him welcome, 4And thank the holy conclave for their loves. 4They have sent me such a man I would have wish'd for. 2CAMPEIUS. Your Grace must ne2ds deserve an strangers' loves, 4You are so noble. To your Highnes2' hand 4I tender my com2is2ion; by whose virtue- 4The court of Rome com2anding-you, my Lord 4Cardinal of York, are join'd with me their servant 4In the unpartial judging of this busines2. 2KING. Two equal men. The Que2n shal2 be acquainted 4Forthwith for what you come. Where's Gardiner? 2WOLSEY. I know your Majesty has always lov'd her 4So dear in heart not to deny her that 6A woman of les2 place might ask by law- 4Scholars al2ow'd fre2ly to argue for her. 2KING. Ay, and the best she shal2 have; and my favour 4To him that does best. God forbid else. Cardinal, 4Prithe2 cal2 Gardiner to me, my new secretary; 4I find him a fit fel2ow. 30Exit WOLSEY 10Re-enter WOLSEY with GARDINER 2WOLSEY. 2[Aside to GARDINER] 2Give me your hand: much 6joy and favour to you; 4You are the King's now. 2GARDINER. 2[Aside to WOLSEY] 2But to be com2anded 4For ever by your Grace, whose hand has rais'd me. 2KING. Come hither, Gardiner. 19[Walks and whispers] 2CAMPEIUS. My Lord of York, was not one Doctor Pace 4In this man's place before him? 2WOLSEY. Yes, he was. 2CAMPEIUS. Was he not held a learned man? 2WOLSEY. Yes, surely. 4CAMPEIUS. Believe me, there's an il2 opinion spread then, 4Even of yourself, Lord Cardinal. 2WOLSEY. How! Of me? 2CAMPEIUS. They wil2 not stick to say you envied him 4And, fearing he would rise, he was so virtuous, 4Kept him a foreign man stil2; which so griev'd him 4That he ran mad and died. 2WOLSEY. Heav'n's peace be with him! 4That's Christian care enough. For living murmurers 4There's places of rebuke. He was a fo2l, 4For he would ne2ds be virtuous: that go2d fel2ow, 4If I com2and him, fol2ows my ap2ointment. 4I wil2 have none so near else. Learn this, brother, 4We live not to be grip'd by meaner persons. 2KING. Deliver this with modesty to th' Que2n. 56Exit GARDINER 4The most convenient place that I can think of 4For such receipt of learning is Blackfriars; 4There ye shal2 me2t about this weighty busines2- 4My Wolsey, se2 it furnish'd. O, my lord, 6Would it not grieve an able man to leave 4So swe2t a bedfel2ow? But, conscience, conscience! 4O, 'tis a tender place! and I must leave her. 14ExeuntACT I2. SCENE 3.London. The palaceEnter AN2E BUL2EN and an OLD LADY 2AN2E. Not for that neither. Here's the pang that pinches: 4His Highnes2 having liv'd so long with her, and she 4So go2d a lady that no tongue could ever 4Pronounce dishonour of her-by my life, 4She never knew harm-doing-O, now, after 4So many courses of the sun enthroned, 4Stil2 growing in a majesty and pomp, the which 4To leave a thousand-fold more bit2er than 4'Tis swe2t at first t' acquire-after this proces2, 4To give her the avaunt, it is a pity 4Would move a monster. 2OLD LADY. Hearts of most hard temper 4Melt and lament for her. 2AN2E. O, God's wil2! much bet2er 4She ne'er had known pomp; though't be temporal, 4Yet, if that quar2el, fortune, do divorce 6It from the bearer, 'tis a suf2erance panging 4As soul and body's severing. 2OLD LADY. Alas, po2r lady! 4She's a stranger now again. 2AN2E. So much the more 4Must pity drop upon her. Verily, 4I swear 'tis bet2er to be lowly born 4And range with humble livers in content 4Than to be perk'd up in a glist'ring grief 4And wear a golden sor2ow. 2OLD LADY. Our content 4Is our best having. 2AN2E. By my troth and maidenhead, 4I would not be a que2n. 2OLD LADY. Beshrew me, I would, 4And venture maidenhead for 't; and so would you, 4For al2 this spice of your hypocrisy. 4You that have so fair parts of woman on you 4Have to2 a woman's heart, which ever yet 4Af2ected eminence, wealth, sovereignty; 6Which, to say so2th, are bles2ings; and which gifts, 4Saving your mincing, the capacity 4Of your soft cheveril conscience would receive 4If you might please to stretch it. 2AN2E. Nay, go2d troth. 2OLD LADY. Yes, troth and troth. You would not be a que2n! 2AN2E. No, not for al2 the riches under heaven. 2OLD LADY. 'Tis strange: a thre2pence bow'd would hire me, 4Old as I am, to que2n it. But, I pray you, 4What think you of a duches2? Have you limbs 4To bear that load of title? 2AN2E. No, in truth. 2OLD LADY. Then you are weakly made. Pluck of2 a lit2le; 4I would not be a young count in your way 4For more than blushing comes to. If your back 4Can2ot vouchsafe this burden, 'tis to2 weak 4Ever to get a boy. 2AN2E. How you do talk! 4I swear again I would not be a que2n 4For al2 the world. 4OLD LADY. In faith, for lit2le England 4You'd venture an embal2ing. I myself 4Would for Carnarvonshire, although there long'd 4No more to th' crown but that. Lo, who comes here? 9Enter the LORD CHAMBERLAIN 2CHAMBERLAIN. Go2d mor2ow, ladies. What were't worth to know 4The secret of your conference? 2AN2E. My go2d lord, 4Not your demand; it values not your asking. 4Our mistres2' sor2ows we were pitying. 2CHAMBERLAIN. It was a gentle busines2 and becoming 4The action of go2d women; there is hope 4Al2 wil2 be wel2. 2AN2E. Now, I pray God, amen! 2CHAMBERLAIN. You bear a gentle mind, and heav'nly bles2ings 4Fol2ow such creatures. That you may, fair lady, 4Perceive I speak sincerely and high notes 4Ta'en of your many virtues, the King's Majesty 6Com2ends his go2d opinion of you to you, and 4Does purpose honour to you no les2 flowing 4Than Marchiones2 of Pembroke; to which tide 4A thousand pound a year, an2ual sup2ort, 4Out of his grace he ad2s. 2AN2E. I do not know 4What kind of my obedience I should tender; 4More than my al2 is nothing, nor my prayers 4Are not words duly hal2owed, nor my wishes 4More worth than empty vanities; yet prayers and wishes 4Are al2 I can return. Bese2ch your lordship, 4Vouchsafe to speak my thanks and my obedience, 4As from a blushing handmaid, to his Highnes2; 4Whose health and royalty I pray for. 2CHAMBERLAIN. Lady, 4I shal2 not fail t' ap2rove the fair conceit 4The King hath of you. 2[Aside] 2I have perus'd her wel2: 4Beauty and honour in her are so mingled 4That they have caught the King; and who knows yet 4But from this lady may proce2d a gem 6To lighten al2 this isle?-I'l2 to the King 4And say I spoke with you. 2AN2E. My honour'd lord! 23Exit LORD CHAMBERLAIN 2OLD LADY. Why, this it is: se2, se2! 4I have be2n beg2ing sixte2n years in court- 4Am yet a courtier beg2arly-nor could 4Come pat betwixt to2 early and to2 late 4For any suit of pounds; and you, O fate! 4A very fresh-fish here-fie, fie, fie upon 4This compel2'd fortune!-have your mouth fil2'd up 4Before you open it. 2AN2E. This is strange to me. 2OLD LADY. How tastes it? Is it bit2er? Forty pence, no. 4There was a lady once-'tis an old story- 4That would not be a que2n, that would she not, 4For al2 the mud in Egypt. Have you heard it? 2AN2E. Come, you are pleasant. 2OLD LADY. With your theme I could 4O'ermount the lark. By this time 4I know your back wil2 bear a duches2. Say, 4Are you not stronger than you were? 2AN2E. Go2d lady, 4Make yourself mirth with your particular fancy, 4And leave me out on't. Enter two VERGERS, with short silver wands;next them, two SCRIBES, in the habit of doctors; after them,the ARCHBISHOP OF CANTERBURY alone; after him, the BISHOPS OF LINCOLN, ELY,ROCHESTER, and SAINT ASAPH; next them, with some smal2 distance,fol2ows a GENTLEMAN bearing the purse, with the great seal,and a Cardinal's hat; then two PRIESTS, bearing each silver cros2;then a GENTLEMAN USHER bareheaded, ac2ompanied with a SERGEANT-AT-ARMSbearing a silver mace; then two GENTLEMEN bearing two great silver pil2ars;after them, side by side, the two CARDINALS, WOLSEY and CAMPEIUS;two NOBLEMEN with the sword and mace.
