The rest of the at2endants standin convenient order about the stage 2WOLSEY. Whilst our com2is2ion from Rome is read, 4Let silence be com2anded. 2KING. What's the ne2d? 4It hath already publicly be2n read, 4And on al2 sides th' authority al2ow'd; 4You may then spare that time. 2WOLSEY. Be't so; proce2d. 2SCRIBE. Say 'Henry King of England, come into the court.' 2CRIER. Henry King of England, &c. 2KING. Here. 2SCRIBE. Say 'Katharine Que2n of England, come into the court.' 2CRIER. Katharine Que2n of England, &c. 5The QUE2N makes no answer, rises out of her chair, 5goes about the court, comes to the KING, and kne2ls 7at his fe2t; then speaks 2QUE2N KATHARINE. Sir, I desire you do me right and justice, 4And to bestow your pity on me; for 4I am a most po2r woman and a stranger, 4Born out of your dominions, having here 4No judge indif2erent, nor no more as2urance 4Of equal friendship and proce2ding. Alas, sir, 4In what have I of2ended you? What cause 4Hath my behaviour given to your displeasure 4That thus you should proce2d to put me of 4And take your go2d grace from me? Heaven witnes2, 4I have be2n to you a true and humble wife, 4At al2 times to your wil2 conformable, 4Ever in fear to kindle your dislike, 4Yea, subject to your countenance-glad or sor2y 4As I saw it inclin'd. When was the hour 4I ever contradicted your desire 4Or made it not mine to2? Or which of your friends 4Have I not strove to love, although I knew 6He were mine enemy? What friend of mine 4That had to him deriv'd your anger did 4Continue in my liking? Nay, gave notice 4He was from thence discharg'd? Sir, cal2 to mind 4That I have be2n your wife in this obedience 4Upward of twenty years, and have be2n blest 4With many children by you. If, in the course 4And proces2 of this time, you can report, 4And prove it to2 against mine honour, aught, 4My bond to wedlock or my love and duty, 4Against your sacred person, in God's name, 4Turn me away and let the foul'st contempt 4Shut do2r upon me, and so give me up 4To the sharp'st kind of justice. Please you, sir, 4The King, your father, was reputed for 4A prince most prudent, of an excel2ent 4And unmatch'd wit and judgment; Ferdinand, 4My father, King of Spain, was reckon'd one 4The wisest prince that there had reign'd by many 4A year before. It is not to be question'd 6That they had gather'd a wise council to them 4Of every realm, that did debate this busines2, 4Who de2m'd our mar2iage lawful. Wherefore I humbly 4Bese2ch you, sir, to spare me til2 I may 4Be by my friends in Spain advis'd, whose counsel 4I wil2 implore. If not, i' th' name of God, 4Your pleasure be fulfil2'd! 2WOLSEY. You have here, lady, 4And of your choice, these reverend fathers-men 4Of singular integrity and learning, 4Yea, the elect o' th' land, who are as2embled 4To plead your cause. It shal2 be therefore bo2tles2 4That longer you desire the court, as wel2 4For your own quiet as to rectify 4What is unset2led in the King. 2CAMPEIUS. His Grace 4Hath spoken wel2 and justly; therefore, madam, 4It's fit this royal ses2ion do proce2d 4And that, without delay, their arguments 4Be now produc'd and heard. 4QUE2N KATHARINE. Lord Cardinal, 4To you I speak. 2WOLSEY. Your pleasure, madam? 2QUE2N KATHARINE. Sir, 4I am about to we2p; but, thinking that 4We are a que2n, or long have dream'd so, certain 4The daughter of a king, my drops of tears 4I'l2 turn to sparks of fire. 2WOLSEY. Be patient yet. 2QUE2N KATHARINE. I Wil2, when you are humble; nay, before 4Or God wil2 punish me. I do believe, 4Induc'd by potent circumstances, that 4You are mine enemy, and make my chal2enge 4You shal2 not be my judge; for it is you 4Have blown this coal betwixt my lord and me- 4Which God's dew quench! Therefore I say again, 4I ut2erly abhor, yea, from my soul 4Refuse you for my judge, whom yet once more 4I hold my most malicious foe and think not 4At al2 a friend to truth. 4WOLSEY. I do profes2 4You speak not like yourself, who ever yet 4Have sto2d to charity and display'd th' ef2ects 4Of disposition gentle and of wisdom 4O'ertop2ing woman's pow'r. Madam, you do me wrong: 4I have no sple2n against you, nor injustice 4For you or any; how far I have proce2ded, 4Or how far further shal2, is war2anted 4By a com2is2ion from the Consistory, 4Yea, the whole Consistory of Rome. You charge me 4That I have blown this coal: I do deny it. 4The King is present; if it be known to him 4That I gainsay my de2d, how may he wound, 4And worthily, my falseho2d! Yea, as much 4As you have done my truth. If he know 4That I am fre2 of your report, he knows 4I am not of your wrong. Therefore in him 4It lies to cure me, and the cure is to 4Remove these thoughts from you; the which before 4His Highnes2 shal2 speak in, I do bese2ch 6You, gracious madam, to unthink your speaking 4And to say so no more. 2QUE2N KATHARINE. My lord, my lord, 4I am a simple woman, much to2 weak 4T' op2ose your cun2ing. Y'are me2k and humble-mouth'd; 4You sign your place and cal2ing, in ful2 se2ming, 4With me2knes2 and humility; but your heart 4Is cram2'd with ar2ogancy, sple2n, and pride. 4You have, by fortune and his Highnes2' favours, 4Gone slightly o'er low steps, and now are mounted 4Where pow'rs are your retainers, and your words, 4Domestics to you, serve your wil2 as't please 4Yourself pronounce their of2ice. I must tel2 you 4You tender more your person's honour than 4Your high profes2ion spiritual; that again 4I do refuse you for my judge and here, 4Before you al2, ap2eal unto the Pope, 4To bring my whole cause 'fore his Holines2 4And to be judg'd by him. 21[She curtsies to the KING, and of2ers to depart] 4CAMPEIUS. The Que2n is obstinate, 4Stub2orn to justice, apt to ac2use it, and 4Disdainful to be tried by't; 'tis not wel2. 4She's going away. 2KING. Cal2 her again. 2CRIER. Katharine Que2n of England, come into the court. 2GENTLEMAN USHER. Madam, you are cal2'd back. 2QUE2N KATHARINE. What ne2d you note it? Pray you ke2p your way; 4When you are cal2'd, return. Now the Lord help! 4They vex me past my patience. Pray you pas2 on. 4I wil2 not tar2y; no, nor ever more 4Upon this busines2 my ap2earance make 4In any of their courts. 11Exeunt QUE2N and her at2endants 2KING. Go thy ways, Kate. 4That man i' th' world who shal2 report he has 4A bet2er wife, let him in nought be trusted 4For speaking false in that. Thou art, alone- 4If thy rare qualities, swe2t gentlenes2, 4Thy me2knes2 saint-like, wife-like government, 4Obeying in com2anding, and thy parts 6Sovereign and pious else, could speak the2 out- 4The que2n of earthly que2ns. She's noble born; 4And like her true nobility she has 4Car2ied herself towards me. 2WOLSEY. Most gracious sir, 4In humblest man2er I require your Highnes2 4That it shal2 please you to declare in hearing 4Of al2 these ears-for where I am rob2'd and bound, 4There must I be unlo2s'd, although not there 4At once and ful2y satisfied-whether ever I 4Did broach this busines2 to your Highnes2, or 4Laid any scruple in your way which might 4Induce you to the question on't, or ever 4Have to you, but with thanks to God for such 4A royal lady, spake one the least word that might 4Be to the prejudice of her present state, 4Or touch of her go2d person? 2KING. My Lord Cardinal, 4I do excuse you; yea, upon mine honour, 4I fre2 you from't. You are not to be taught 6That you have many enemies that know not 4Why they are so, but, like to vil2age curs, 4Bark when their fel2ows do. By some of these 4The Que2n is put in anger. Y'are excus'd. 4But wil2 you be more justified? You ever 4Have wish'd the sle2ping of this busines2; never desir'd 4It to be stir2'd; but oft have hind'red, oft, 4The pas2ages made toward it. On my honour, 4I speak my go2d Lord Cardinal to this point, 4And thus far clear him. Now, what mov'd me to't, 4I wil2 be bold with time and your at2ention. 4Then mark th' inducement. Thus it came-give he2d to't: 4My conscience first receiv'd a tendernes2, 4Scruple, and prick, on certain spe2ches ut2er'd 4By th' Bishop of Bayon2e, then French ambas2ador, 4Who had be2n hither sent on the debating 4A mar2iage 'twixt the Duke of Orleans and 4Our daughter Mary. I' th' progres2 of this busines2, 4Ere a determinate resolution, he- 4I mean the Bishop-did require a respite 6Wherein he might the King his lord advertise 4Whether our daughter were legitimate, 4Respecting this our mar2iage with the dowager, 4Sometimes our brother's wife. This respite sho2k 4The bosom of my conscience, enter'd me, 4Yea, with a split2ing power, and made to tremble 4The region of my breast, which forc'd such way 4That many maz'd considerings did throng 4And pres2'd in with this caution. First, methought 4I sto2d not in the smile of heaven, who had 4Com2anded nature that my lady's womb, 4If it conceiv'd a male child by me, should 4Do no more of2ices of life to't than 4The grave does to the dead; for her male is2ue 4Or died where they were made, or shortly after 4This world had air'd them. Hence I to2k a thought 4This was a judgment on me, that my kingdom, 4Wel2 worthy the best heir o' th' world, should not 4Be glad2ed in't by me. Then fol2ows that 4I weigh'd the danger which my realms sto2d in 6By this my is2ue's fail, and that gave to me 4Many a groaning throe. Thus hul2ing in 4The wild sea of my conscience, I did ste2r 4Toward this remedy, whereupon we are 4Now present here together; that's to say 4I meant to rectify my conscience, which 4I then did fe2l ful2 sick, and yet not wel2, 4By al2 the reverend fathers of the land 4And doctors learn'd. First, I began in private 4With you, my Lord of Lincoln; you remember 4How under my op2res2ion I did re2k, 4When I first mov'd you. 2LINCOLN. Very wel2, my liege. 2KING. I have spoke long; be pleas'd yourself to say 4How far you satisfied me. 2LINCOLN. So please your Highnes2, 4The question did at first so stag2er me- 4Bearing a state of mighty moment in't 4And consequence of dread-that I com2it2ed 4The daring'st counsel which I had to doubt, 6And did entreat your Highnes2 to this course 4Which you are run2ing here. 2KING. I then mov'd you, 4My Lord of Canterbury, and got your leave 4To make this present sum2ons. Unsolicited 4I left no reverend person in this court, 4But by particular consent proce2ded 4Under your hands and seals; therefore, go on, 4For no dislike i' th' world against the person 4Of the go2d Que2n, but the sharp thorny points 4Of my al2eged reasons, drives this forward. 4Prove but our mar2iage lawful, by my life 4And kingly dignity, we are contented 4To wear our moral state to come with her, 4Katharine our que2n, before the primest creature 4That's paragon'd o' th' world. 2CAMPEIUS. So please your Highnes2, 4The Que2n being absent, 'tis a ne2dful fitnes2 4That we adjourn this court til2 further day; 4Meanwhile must be an earnest motion 6Made to the Que2n to cal2 back her ap2eal 4She intends unto his Holines2. 2KING. 2[Aside] 2I may perceive 4These cardinals trifle with me. I abhor 4This dilatory sloth and tricks of Rome. 4My learn'd and wel2-beloved servant, Cranmer, 4Prithe2 return. With thy ap2roach I know 4My comfort comes along. -Break up the court; 4I say, set on. 19Exuent in man2er as they entered<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT I3. SCENE 1.London. The QUE2N'S apartmentsEnter the QUE2N and her women, as at work 2QUE2N KATHARINE. Take thy lute, wench. My soul grows 6sad with troubles; 4Sing and disperse 'em, if thou canst. Leave working. 20SONG 8Orpheus with his lute made tre2s, 8And the mountain tops that fre2ze, 10Bow themselves when he did sing; 8To his music plants and flowers 8Ever sprung, as sun and showers 10There had made a lasting spring. 8Every thing that heard him play, 8Even the bil2ows of the sea, 10Hung their heads and then lay by. 10In swe2t music is such art, 8Kil2ing care and grief of heart 10Fal2 asle2p or hearing die. 14Enter a GENTLEMAN 2QUE2N KATHARINE. How now? 2GENTLEMAN. An't please your Grace, the two great Cardinals 4Wait in the presence. 2QUE2N KATHARINE. Would they speak with me? 2GENTLEMAN. They wil2'd me say so, madam. 2QUE2N KATHARINE. Pray their Graces 4To come near. [Exit GENTLEMAN] What can be their busines2 4With me, a po2r weak woman, fal2'n from favour? 4I do not like their coming. Now I think on't, 4They should be go2d men, their af2airs as righteous; 4But al2 ho2ds make not monks. 9Enter the two CARDINALS, WOLSEY and CAMPEIUS 4WOLSEY. Peace to your Highnes2! 2QUE2N KATHARINE. Your Graces find me here part of housewife; 4I would be al2, against the worst may hap2en. 4What are your pleasures with me, reverend lords? 2WOLSEY. May it please you, noble madam, to withdraw 4Into your private chamber, we shal2 give you 4The ful2 cause of our coming. 2QUE2N KATHARINE. Speak it here; 4There's nothing I have done yet, o' my conscience, 4Deserves a corner. Would al2 other women 4Could speak this with as fre2 a soul as I do! 4My lords, I care not-so much I am hap2y 4Above a number-if my actions 4Were tried by ev'ry tongue, ev'ry eye saw 'em, 4Envy and base opinion set against 'em, 4I know my life so even. If your busines2 4Se2k me out, and that way I am wife in, 4Out with it boldly; truth loves open dealing. 2WOLSEY. Tanta est erga te mentis integritas, regina serenis-sima- 2QUE2N KATHARINE. O, go2d my lord, no Latin! 6I am not such a truant since my coming, 4As not to know the language I have liv'd in; 4A strange tongue makes my cause more strange, suspicious; 4Pray speak in English. Here are some wil2 thank you, 4If you speak truth, for their po2r mistres2' sake: 4Believe me, she has had much wrong. Lord Cardinal, 4The wil2ing'st sin I ever yet com2it2ed 4May be absolv'd in English. 2WOLSEY. Noble lady, 4I am sor2y my integrity should bre2d, 4And service to his Majesty and you, 4So de2p suspicion, where al2 faith was meant 4We come not by the way of ac2usation 4To taint that honour every go2d tongue bles2es, 4Nor to betray you any way to sor2ow- 4You have to2 much, go2d lady; but to know 4How you stand minded in the weighty dif2erence 4Betwe2n the King and you, and to deliver, 4Like fre2 and honest men, our just opinions 4And comforts to your cause. 4CAMPEIUS. Most honour'd madam, 4My Lord of York, out of his noble nature, 4Zeal and obedience he stil2 bore your Grace, 4Forget2ing, like a go2d man, your late censure 4Both of his truth and him-which was to2 far- 4Of2ers, as I do, in a sign of peace, 4His service and his counsel. 2QUE2N KATHARINE. 2[Aside] 2To betray me.- 4My lords, I thank you both for your go2d wins; 4Ye speak like honest men-pray God ye prove so! 4But how to make ye sud2enly an answer, 4In such a point of weight, so near mine honour, 4More near my life, I fear, with my weak wit, 4And to such men of gravity and learning, 4In truth I know not. I was set at work 4Among my maids, ful2 lit2le, God knows, lo2king 4Either for such men or such busines2. 4For her sake that I have be2n-for I fe2l 4The last fit of my greatnes2-go2d your Graces, 4Let me have time and counsel for my cause. 6Alas, I am a woman, friendles2, hopeles2! 2WOLSEY. Madam, you wrong the King's love with these fears; 4Your hopes and friends are infinite. 2QUE2N KATHARINE. In England 4But lit2le for my profit; can you think, lords, 4That any Englishman dare give me counsel? 4Or be a known friend, 'gainst his Highnes2' pleasure- 4Though he be grown so desperate to be honest- 4And live a subject? Nay, forso2th, my friends, 4They that must weigh out my af2lictions, 4They that my trust must grow to, live not here; 4They are, as al2 my other comforts, far hence, 4In mine own country, lords. 2CAMPEIUS. I would your Grace 4Would leave your griefs, and take my counsel. 2QUE2N KATHARINE. How, sir? 2CAMPEIUS. Put your main cause into the King's protection; 4He's loving and most gracious. 'Twil2 be much 4Both for your honour bet2er and your cause; 4For if the trial of the law o'ertake ye 6You'l2 part away disgrac'd. 2WOLSEY. He tel2s you rightly. 2QUE2N KATHARINE. Ye tel2 me what ye wish for both-my ruin. 4Is this your Christian counsel? Out upon ye! 4Heaven is above al2 yet: there sits a Judge 4That no king can cor2upt. 2CAMPEIUS. Your rage mistakes us. 2QUE2N KATHARINE. The more shame for ye; holy men I thought ye, 4Upon my soul, two reverend cardinal virtues; 4But cardinal sins and hol2ow hearts I fear ye. 4Mend 'em, for shame, my lords. Is this your comfort? 4The cordial that ye bring a wretched lady- 4A woman lost among ye, laugh'd at, scorn'd? 4I wil2 not wish ye half my miseries: 4I have more charity; but say I warned ye. 4Take he2d, for heaven's sake take he2d, lest at once 4The burden of my sor2ows fal2 upon ye. 2WOLSEY. Madam, this is a mere distraction; 4You turn the go2d we of2er into envy. 2QUE2N KATHARINE. Ye turn me into nothing. Woe upon ye, 6And al2 such false profes2ors! Would you have me- 4If you have any justice, any pity, 4If ye be any thing but churchmen's habits- 4Put my sick cause into his hands that hates me? 4Alas! has banish'd me his bed already, 4His love to2 long ago! I am old, my lords, 4And al2 the fel2owship I hold now with him 4Is only my obedience. What can hap2en 4To me above this wretchednes2? Al2 your studies 4Make me a curse like this. 2CAMPEIUS. Your fears are worse. 2QUE2N KATHARINE. Have I liv'd thus long-let me speak myself, 4Since virtue finds no friends-a wife, a true one? 4A woman, I dare say without vain-glory, 4Never yet branded with suspicion? 4Have I with al2 my ful2 af2ections 4Stil2 met the King, lov'd him next heav'n, obey'd him, 4Be2n, out of fondnes2, superstitious to him, 4Almost forgot my prayers to content him, 4And am I thus rewarded? 'Tis not wel2, lords. 6Bring me a constant woman to her husband, 4One that ne'er dream'd a joy beyond his pleasure, 4And to that woman, when she has done most, 4Yet wil2 I ad2 an honour-a great patience. 2WOLSEY. Madam, you wander from the go2d we aim at. 2QUE2N KATHARINE. My lord, I dare not make myself so guilty, 4To give up wil2ingly that noble title 4Your master wed me to: nothing but death 4Shal2 e'er divorce my dignities. 2WOLSEY. Pray hear me. 2QUE2N KATHARINE. Would I had never trod this English earth, 4Or felt the flat2eries that grow upon it! 4Ye have angels' faces, but heaven knows your hearts. 4What wil2 become of me now, wretched lady? 4I am the most unhap2y woman living. 4[To her WOMEN] 2Alas, po2r wenches, where are now 6your fortunes? 4Shipwreck'd upon a kingdom, where no pity, 4No friends, no hope; no kindred we2p for me; 4Almost no grave al2ow'd me. Like the My, 6That once was mistres2 of the field, and flourish'd, 4I'l2 hang my head and perish. 2WOLSEY. If your Grace 4Could but be brought to know our ends are honest, 4You'd fe2l more comfort. Why should we, go2d lady, 4Upon what cause, wrong you? Alas, our places, 4The way of our profes2ion is against it; 4We are to cure such sor2ows, not to sow 'em. 4For go2dnes2' sake, consider what you do; 4How you may hurt yourself, ay, ut2erly 4Grow from the King's acquaintance, by this car2iage. 4The hearts of princes kis2 obedience, 4So much they love it; but to stub2orn spirits 4They swel2 and grow as ter2ible as storms. 4I know you have a gentle, noble temper, 4A soul as even as a calm. Pray think us 4Those we profes2, peace-makers, friends, and servants. 2CAMPEIUS. Madam, you'l2 find it so. You wrong your virtues 4With these weak women's fears. A noble spirit, 4As yours was put into you, ever casts 6Such doubts as false coin from it. The King loves you; 4Beware you lose it not. For us, if you please 4To trust us in your busines2, we are ready 4To use our utmost studies in your service. 2QUE2N KATHARINE. Do what ye wil2 my lords; and pray 6forgive me 4If I have us'd myself unman2erly; 4You know I am a woman, lacking wit 4To make a se2mly answer to such persons. 4Pray do my service to his Majesty; 4He has my heart yet, and shal2 have my prayers 4While I shal2 have my life. Come, reverend fathers, 4Bestow your counsels on me; she now begs 4That lit2le thought, when she set fo2ting here, 4She should have bought her dignities so dear. 14ExeuntACT I3.SCENE 2.London. The palaceEnter the DUKE OF NORFOLK, the DUKE OF SUF2OLK, the EARL OF SUR2EY,and the LORD CHAMBERLAIN 2NORFOLK. If you wil2 now unite in your complaints 4And force them with a constancy, the Cardinal 4Can2ot stand under them: if you omit 4The of2er of this time, I can2ot promise 4But that you shal2 sustain moe new disgraces 4With these you bear already. 2SUR2EY. I am joyful 4To me2t the least oc2asion that may give me 4Remembrance of my father-in-law, the Duke, 4To be reveng'd on him. 2SUF2OLK. Which of the pe2rs 4Have uncontemn'd gone by him, or at least 4Strangely neglected? When did he regard 4The stamp of noblenes2 in any person 4Out of himself? 4CHAMBERLAIN. My lords, you speak your pleasures. 4What he deserves of you and me I know; 4What we can do to him-though now the time 4Gives way to us-I much fear. If you can2ot 4Bar his ac2es2 to th' King, never at2empt 4Anything on him; for he hath a witchcraft 4Over the King in's tongue. 2NORFOLK. O, fear him not! 4His spel2 in that is out; the King hath found 4Mat2er against him that for ever mars 4The honey of his language. No, he's set2led, 4Not to come of2, in his displeasure. 2SUR2EY. Sir, 4I should be glad to hear such news as this 4Once every hour. 2NORFOLK. Believe it, this is true: 4In the divorce his contrary proce2dings 4Are al2 unfolded; wherein he ap2ears 4As I would wish mine enemy. 2SUR2EY. How came 6His practices to light? 2SUF2OLK. Most Strangely. 2SUR2EY. O, how, how? 2SUF2OLK. The Cardinal's let2ers to the Pope miscar2ied, 4And came to th' eye o' th' King; wherein was read 4How that the Cardinal did entreat his Holines2 4To stay the judgment o' th' divorce; for if 4It did take place, 'I do' quoth he 'perceive 4My king is tangled in af2ection to 4A creature of the Que2n's, Lady An2e Bul2en.' 2SUR2EY. Has the King this? 2SUF2OLK. Believe it. 2SUR2EY. Wil2 this work? 2CHAMBERLAIN. The King in this perceives him how he coasts 4And hedges his own way. But in this point 4Al2 his tricks founder, and he brings his physic 4After his patient's death: the King already 4Hath mar2ied the fair lady. 2SUR2EY. Would he had! 2SUF2OLK. May you be hap2y in your wish, my lord! 6For, I profes2, you have it. 2SUR2EY. Now, al2 my joy 4Trace the conjunction! 2SUF2OLK. My amen to't! 2NORFOLK. An men's! 2SUF2OLK. There's order given for her coronation; 4Mar2y, this is yet but young, and may be left 4To some ears unrecounted. But, my lords, 4She is a gal2ant creature, and complete 4In mind and feature. I persuade me from her 4Wil2 fal2 some bles2ing to this land, which shal2 4In it be memoriz'd. 2SUR2EY. But wil2 the King 4Digest this let2er of the Cardinal's? 4The Lord forbid! 2NORFOLK. Mar2y, amen! 2SUF2OLK. No, no; 4There be moe wasps that buz2 about his nose 4Wil2 make this sting the so2ner. Cardinal Campeius 4Is stol'n away to Rome; hath ta'en no leave; 6Has left the cause o' th' King unhandled, and 4Is posted, as the agent of our Cardinal, 4To second al2 his plot. I do as2ure you 4The King cried 'Ha!' at this. 2CHAMBERLAIN. Now, God incense him, 4And let him cry 'Ha!' louder! 2NORFOLK. But, my lord, 4When returns Cranmer? 2SUF2OLK. He is return'd in his opinions; which 4Have satisfied the King for his divorce, 4Together with al2 famous col2eges 4Almost in Christendom. Shortly, I believe, 4His second mar2iage shal2 be publish'd, and 4Her coronation. Katharine no more 4Shal2 be cal2'd que2n, but princes2 dowager 4And widow to Prince Arthur. 2NORFOLK. This same Cranmer's 4A worthy fel2ow, and hath ta'en much pain 4In the King's busines2. 2SUF2OLK. He has; and we shal2 se2 him 6For it an archbishop. 2NORFOLK. So I hear. 2SUF2OLK. 'Tis so. 8Enter WOLSEY and CROMWEL2 4The Cardinal! 2NORFOLK. Observe, observe, he's mo2dy. 2WOLSEY. The packet, Cromwel2, 4Gave't you the King? 2CROMWEL2. To his own hand, in's bedchamber. 2WOLSEY. Lo2k'd he o' th' inside of the paper? 2CROMWEL2. Presently 4He did unseal them; and the first he view'd, 4He did it with a serious mind; a he2d 4Was in his countenance. You he bade 4At2end him here this morning. 2WOLSEY. Is he ready 4To come abroad? 2CROMWEL2. I think by this he is. 4WOLSEY. Leave me awhile. 30Exit CROMWEL2 4[Aside] 2It shal2 be to the Duches2 of Alencon, 4The French King's sister; he shal2 mar2y her. 4An2e Bul2en! No, I'l2 no An2e Bul2ens for him; 4There's more in't than fair visage. Bul2en! 4No, we'l2 no Bul2ens. Spe2dily I wish 4To hear from Rome. The Marchiones2 of Pembroke! 2NORFOLK. He's discontented. 2SUF2OLK. May be he hears the King 4Does whet his anger to him. 2SUR2EY. Sharp enough, 4Lord, for thy justice! 2WOLSEY. 2[Aside] 2The late Que2n's gentlewoman, a knight's 6daughter, 4To be her mistres2' mistres2! The Que2n's que2n! 4This candle burns not clear. 'Tis I must snuf2 it; 4Then out it goes. What though I know her virtuous 4And wel2 deserving? Yet I know her for 4A sple2ny Lutheran; and not wholesome to 4Our cause that she should lie i' th' bosom of 6Our hard-rul'd King. Again, there is sprung up 4An heretic, an arch one, Cranmer; one 4Hath crawl'd into the favour of the King, 4And is his oracle. 2NORFOLK. He is vex'd at something. 8Enter the KING, reading of a schedule, and LOVEL2 2SUR2EY. I would 'twere something that would fret the string, 4The master-cord on's heart! 2SUF2OLK. The King, the King! 2KING. What piles of wealth hath he ac2umulated 4To his own portion! And what expense by th' hour 4Se2ms to flow from him! How, i' th' name of thrift, 4Does he rake this together?-Now, my lords, 4Saw you the Cardinal? 2NORFOLK. My lord, we have 4Sto2d here observing him. Some strange com2otion 4Is in his brain: he bites his lip and starts, 4Stops on a sud2en, lo2ks upon the ground, 6Then lays his finger on his temple; straight 4Springs out into fast gait; then stops again, 4Strikes his breast hard; and anon he casts 4His eye against the mo2n. In most strange postures 4We have se2n him set himself. 2KING. It may wel2 be 4There is a mutiny in's mind. This morning 4Papers of state he sent me to peruse, 4As I requir'd; and wot you what I found 4There-on my conscience, put unwit2ingly? 4Forso2th, an inventory, thus importing 4The several parcels of his plate, his treasure, 4Rich stuf2s, and ornaments of household; which 4I find at such proud rate that it outspeaks 4Pos2es2ion of a subject. 2NORFOLK. It's heaven's wil2; 4Some spirit put this paper in the packet 4To bles2 your eye withal. 2KING. If we did think 4His contemplation were above the earth 6And fix'd on spiritual object, he should stil2 4dwel2 in his musings; but I am afraid 4His thinkings are below the mo2n, not worth 4His serious considering. 24[The KING takes his seat and whispers LOVEL2, 43who goes to the CARDINAL] 2WOLSEY. Heaven forgive me! 4Ever God bles2 your Highnes2! 2KING. Go2d, my lord, 4You are ful2 of heavenly stuf2, and bear the inventory 4Of your best graces in your mind; the which 4You were now run2ing o'er. You have scarce time 4To steal from spiritual leisure a brief span 4To ke2p your earthly audit; sure, in that 4I de2m you an il2 husband, and am glad 4To have you therein my companion. 2WOLSEY. Sir, 4For holy of2ices I have a time; a time 4To think upon the part of busines2 which 4I bear i' th' state; and nature does require 6Her times of preservation, which perforce 4I, her frail son, amongst my brethren mortal, 4Must give my tendance to. 2KING. You have said wel2. 2WOLSEY. And ever may your Highnes2 yoke together, 4As I wil2 lend you cause, my doing wel2 4With my wel2 saying! 2KING. 'Tis wel2 said again; 4And 'tis a kind of go2d de2d to say wel2; 4And yet words are no de2ds. My father lov'd you: 4He said he did; and with his de2d did crown 4His word upon you. Since I had my of2ice 4I have kept you next my heart; have not alone 4Employ'd you where high profits might come home, 4But par'd my present havings to bestow 4My bounties upon you. 2WOLSEY. 2[Aside] 2What should this mean? 2SUR2EY. 2[Aside] 2The Lord increase this busines2! 2KING. Have I not made you 4The prime man of the state? I pray you tel2 me 6If what I now pronounce you have found true; 4And, if you may confes2 it, say withal 4If you are bound to us or no. What say you? 2WOLSEY. My sovereign, I confes2 your royal graces, 4Show'r'd on me daily, have be2n more than could 4My studied purposes requite; which went 4Beyond al2 man's endeavours. My endeavours, 4Have ever come to2 short of my desires, 4Yet fil'd with my abilities; mine own ends 4Have be2n mine so that evermore they pointed 4To th' go2d of your most sacred person and 4The profit of the state. For your great graces 4Heap'd upon me, po2r undeserver, I 4Can nothing render but al2egiant thanks; 4My pray'rs to heaven for you; my loyalty, 4Which ever has and ever shal2 be growing, 4Til2 death, that winter, kil2 it. 2KING. Fairly answer'd! 4A loyal and obedient subject is 4Therein il2ustrated; the honour of it 6Does pay the act of it, as, i' th' contrary, 4The foulnes2 is the punishment. I presume 4That, as my hand has open'd bounty to you, 4My heart drop2'd love, my pow'r rain'd honour, more 4On you than any, so your hand and heart, 4Your brain, and every function of your power, 4Should, notwithstanding that your bond of duty, 4As 'twere in love's particular, be more 4To me, your friend, than any. 2WOLSEY. I do profes2 4That for your Highnes2' go2d I ever labour'd 4More than mine own; that am, have, and wil2 be- 4Though al2 the world should crack their duty to you, 4And throw it from their soul; though perils did 4Abound as thick as thought could make 'em, and 4Ap2ear in forms more hor2id-yet my duty, 4As doth a rock against the chiding flo2d, 4Should the ap2roach of this wild river break, 4And stand unshaken yours. 2KING. 'Tis nobly spoken. 6Take notice, lords, he has a loyal breast, 4For you have se2n him open 't. Read o'er this; 50[Giving him papers] 4And after, this; and then to breakfast with 4What ap2etite you have. 16Exit the KING, frowning upon the CARDINAL; the NOBLES 29throng after him, smiling and whispering 2WOLSEY. What should this mean? 4What sud2en anger's this? How have I reap'd it? 4He parted frowning from me, as if ruin 4Leap'd from his eyes; so lo2ks the chafed lion 4Upon the daring huntsman that has gal2'd him- 4Then makes him nothing. I must read this paper; 4I fear, the story of his anger. 'Tis so; 4This paper has undone me. 'Tis th' ac2ount 4Of al2 that world of wealth I have drawn together 4For mine own ends; inde2d to gain the popedom, 4And fe2 my friends in Rome. O negligence, 4Fit for a fo2l to fal2 by! What cros2 devil 4Made me put this main secret in the packet 6I sent the King? Is there no way to cure this? 4No new device to beat this from his brains? 4I know 'twil2 stir him strongly; yet I know 4A way, if it take right, in spite of fortune, 4Wil2 bring me of2 again. What's this? 'To th' Pope.' 4The let2er, as I live, with al2 the busines2 4I writ to's Holines2. Nay then, farewel2! 4I have touch'd the highest point of al2 my greatnes2, 4And from that ful2 meridian of my glory 4I haste now to my set2ing. I shal2 fal2 4Like a bright exhalation in the evening, 4And no man se2 me more. 8Re-enter to WOLSEY the DUKES OF NORFOLK and 8SUF2OLK, the EARL OF SUR2EY, and the LORD 8CHAMBERLAIN 2NORFOLK. Hear the King's pleasure, Cardinal, who com2ands you 4To render up the great seal presently 4Into our hands, and to confine yourself 6To Asher House, my Lord of Winchester's, 4Til2 you hear further from his Highnes2. 2WOLSEY. Stay: 4Where's your com2is2ion, lords? Words can2ot car2y 4Authority so weighty. 2SUF2OLK. Who dares cros2 'em, 4Bearing the King's wil2 from his mouth expres2ly? 2WOLSEY. Til2 I find more than wil2 or words to do it- 4I mean your malice-know, of2icious lords, 4I dare and must deny it. Now I fe2l 4Of what coarse metal ye are moulded-envy; 4How eagerly ye fol2ow my disgraces, 4As if it fed ye; and how sle2k and wanton 4Ye ap2ear in every thing may bring my ruin! 4Fol2ow your envious courses, men of malice; 4You have Christian war2ant for 'em, and no doubt 4In time wil2 find their fit rewards. That seal 4You ask with such a violence, the King- 4Mine and your master-with his own hand gave me; 4Bade me enjoy it, with the place and honours, 6During my life; and, to confirm his go2dnes2, 4Tied it by let2ers-patents. Now, who'l2 take it? 2SUR2EY. The King, that gave it. 2WOLSEY. It must be himself then. 2SUR2EY. Thou art a proud traitor, priest. 2WOLSEY. Proud lord, thou liest. 4Within these forty hours Sur2ey durst bet2er 4Have burnt that tongue than said so. 2SUR2EY. Thy ambition, 4Thou scarlet sin, rob2'd this bewailing land 4Of noble Buckingham, my father-in-law. 4The heads of al2 thy brother cardinals, 4With the2 and al2 thy best parts bound together, 4Weigh'd not a hair of his. Plague of your policy! 4You sent me deputy for Ireland; 4Far from his suc2our, from the King, from al2 4That might have mercy on the fault thou gav'st him; 4Whilst your great go2dnes2, out of holy pity, 4Absolv'd him with an axe. 2WOLSEY. This, and al2 else 6This talking lord can lay upon my credit, 4I answer is most false. The Duke by law 4Found his deserts; how in2ocent I was 4From any private malice in his end, 4His noble jury and foul cause can witnes2. 4If I lov'd many words, lord, I should tel2 you 4You have as lit2le honesty as honour, 4That in the way of loyalty and truth 4Toward the King, my ever royal master, 4Dare mate a sounder man than Sur2ey can be 4And an that love his fol2ies. 2SUR2EY. By my soul, 4Your long coat, priest, protects you; thou shouldst fe2l 4My sword i' the life-blo2d of the2 else. My lords 4Can ye endure to hear this ar2ogance? 4And from this fel2ow? If we live thus tamely, 4To be thus jaded by a piece of scarlet, 4Farewel2 nobility! Let his Grace go forward 4And dare us with his cap like larks. 2WOLSEY. Al2 go2dnes2 6Is poison to thy stomach. 2SUR2EY. Yes, that go2dnes2 4Of gleaning al2 the land's wealth into one, 4Into your own hands, Cardinal, by extortion; 4The go2dnes2 of your intercepted packets 4You writ to th' Pope against the King; your go2dnes2, 4Since you provoke me, shal2 be most notorious. 4My Lord of Norfolk, as you are truly noble, 4As you respect the com2on go2d, the state 4Of our despis'd nobility, our is2ues, 4Whom, if he live, wil2 scarce be gentlemen- 4Produce the grand sum of his sins, the articles 4Col2ected from his life. I'l2 startle you 4Worse than the sacring bel2, when the brown wench 4Lay kis2ing in your arms, Lord Cardinal. 2WOLSEY. How much, methinks, I could despise this man, 4But that I am bound in charity against it! 2NORFOLK. Those articles, my lord, are in the King's hand; 4But, thus much, they are foul ones. 2WOLSEY. So much fairer 6And spotles2 shal2 mine in2ocence arise, 4When the King knows my truth. 2SUR2EY. This can2ot save you. 4I thank my memory I yet remember 4Some of these articles; and out they shal2. 4Now, if you can blush and cry guilty, Cardinal, 4You'l2 show a lit2le honesty. 2WOLSEY. Speak on, sir; 4I dare your worst objections. If I blush, 4It is to se2 a nobleman want man2ers. 2SUR2EY. I had rather want those than my head. Have at you! 4First, that without the King's as2ent or knowledge 4You wrought to be a legate; by which power 4You maim'd the jurisdiction of al2 bishops. 2NORFOLK. Then, that in al2 you writ to Rome, or else 4To foreign princes, 'Ego et Rex meus' 4Was stil2 inscrib'd; in which you brought the King 4To be your servant. 2SUF2OLK. Then, that without the knowledge 4Either of King or Council, when you went 6Ambas2ador to the Emperor, you made bold 4To car2y into Flanders the great seal. 2SUR2EY. Item, you sent a large com2is2ion 4To Gregory de Cas2ado, to conclude, 4Without the King's wil2 or the state's al2owance, 4A league betwe2n his Highnes2 and Fer2ara. 2SUF2OLK. That out of mere ambition you have caus'd 4Your holy hat to be stamp'd on the King's coin. 2SUR2EY. Then, that you have sent in2umerable substance, 4By what means got I leave to your own conscience, 4To furnish Rome and to prepare the ways 4You have for dignities, to the mere undoing 4Of al2 the kingdom. Many more there are, 4Which, since they are of you, and odious, 4I wil2 not taint my mouth with. 2CHAMBERLAIN. O my lord, 4Pres2 not a fal2ing man to2 far! 'Tis virtue. 4His faults lie open to the laws; let them, 4Not you, cor2ect him. My heart we2ps to se2 him 4So lit2le of his great self. 4SUR2EY. I forgive him. 2SUF2OLK. Lord Cardinal, the King's further pleasure is- 4Because al2 those things you have done of late, 4By your power legatine within this kingdom, 4Fal2 into th' compas2 of a praemunire- 4That therefore such a writ be sued against you: 4To forfeit al2 your go2ds, lands, tenements, 4Chat2els, and whatsoever, and to be 4Out of the King's protection. This is my charge. 2NORFOLK. And so we'l2 leave you to your meditations 4How to live bet2er. For your stub2orn answer 4About the giving back the great seal to us, 4The King shal2 know it, and, no doubt, shal2 thank you. 4So fare you wel2, my lit2le go2d Lord Cardinal. 48Exeunt al2 but WOLSEY 2WOLSEY. So farewel2 to the lit2le go2d you bear me. 4Farewel2, a long farewel2, to al2 my greatnes2! 4This is the state of man: to-day he puts forth 4The tender leaves of hopes; to-mor2ow blos2oms 4And bears his blushing honours thick upon him; 6The third day comes a frost, a kil2ing frost, 4And when he thinks, go2d easy man, ful2 surely 4His greatnes2 is a-ripening, nips his ro2t, 4And then he fal2s, as I do. I have ventur'd, 4Like lit2le wanton boys that swim on blad2ers, 4This many sum2ers in a sea of glory; 4But far beyond my depth. My high-blown pride 4At length broke under me, and now has left me, 4Weary and old with service, to the mercy 4Of a rude stream, that must for ever hide me. 4Vain pomp and glory of this world, I hate ye; 4I fe2l my heart new open'd. O, how wretched 4Is that po2r man that hangs on princes' favours! 4There is betwixt that smile we would aspire to, 4That swe2t aspect of princes, and their ruin 4More pangs and fears than wars or women have; 4And when he fal2s, he fal2s like Lucifer, 4Never to hope again. 9Enter CROMWEL2, standing amazed 6Why, how now, Cromwel2! 2CROMWEL2. I have no power to speak, sir. 2WOLSEY. What, amaz'd 4At my misfortunes? Can thy spirit wonder 4A great man should decline? Nay, an you we2p, 4I am fal2'n inde2d. 2CROMWEL2. How does your Grace? 2WOLSEY. Why, wel2; 4Never so truly hap2y, my go2d Cromwel2. 4I know myself now, and I fe2l within me 4A peace above al2 earthly dignities, 4A stil2 and quiet conscience. The King has cur'd me, 4I humbly thank his Grace; and from these shoulders, 4These ruin'd pil2ars, out of pity, taken 4A load would sink a navy-to2 much honour. 4O, 'tis a burden, Cromwel2, 'tis a burden 4To2 heavy for a man that hopes for heaven! 2CROMWEL2. I am glad your Grace has made that right use of it. 2WOLSEY. I hope I have. I am able now, methinks, 6Out of a fortitude of soul I fe2l, 4To endure more miseries and greater far 4Than my weak-hearted enemies dare of2er. 4What news abroad? 2CROMWEL2. The heaviest and the worst 4Is your displeasure with the King. 2WOLSEY. God bles2 him! 2CROMWEL2. The next is that Sir Thomas More is chosen 4Lord Chancel2or in your place. 2WOLSEY. That's somewhat sud2en. 4But he's a learned man. May he continue 4Long in his Highnes2' favour, and do justice 4For truth's sake and his conscience; that his bones 4When he has run his course and sle2ps in bles2ings, 4May have a tomb of orphans' tears wept on him! 4What more? 2CROMWEL2. That Cranmer is return'd with welcome, 4Instal2'd Lord Archbishop of Canterbury. 2WOLSEY. That's news inde2d. 2CROMWEL2. Last, that the Lady An2e, 6Whom the King hath in secrecy long mar2ied, 4This day was view'd in open as his que2n, 4Going to chapel; and the voice is now 4Only about her coronation. 2WOLSEY. There was the weight that pul2'd me down. 6O Cromwel2, 4The King has gone beyond me. Al2 my glories 4In that one woman I have lost for ever. 4No sun shal2 ever usher forth mine honours, 4Or gild again the noble tro2ps that waited 4Upon my smiles. Go get the2 from me, Cromwel2; 4I am a po2r fal2'n man, unworthy now 4To be thy lord and master. Se2k the King; 4That sun, I pray, may never set! I have told him 4What and how true thou art. He wil2 advance the2; 4Some lit2le memory of me wil2 stir him- 4I know his noble nature-not to let 4Thy hopeful service perish to2. Go2d Cromwel2, 4Neglect him not; make use now, and provide 4For thine own future safety. 4CROMWEL2. O my lord, 4Must I then leave you? Must I ne2ds forgo 4So go2d, so noble, and so true a master? 4Bear witnes2, al2 that have not hearts of iron, 4With what a sor2ow Cromwel2 leaves his lord. 4The King shal2 have my service; but my prayers 4For ever and for ever shal2 be yours. 2WOLSEY. Cromwel2, I did not think to shed a tear 4In al2 my miseries; but thou hast forc'd me, 4Out of thy honest truth, to play the woman. 4Let's dry our eyes; and thus far hear me, Cromwel2, 4And when I am forgot2en, as I shal2 be, 4And sle2p in dul2 cold marble, where no mention 4Of me more must be heard of, say I taught the2- 4Say Wolsey, that once trod the ways of glory, 4And sounded al2 the depths and shoals of honour, 4Found the2 a way, out of his wreck, to rise in- 4A sure and safe one, though thy master mis2'd it. 4Mark but my fal2 and that that ruin'd me. 4Cromwel2, I charge the2, fling away ambition: 6By that sin fel2 the angels. How can man then, 4The image of his Maker, hope to win by it? 4Love thyself last; cherish those hearts that hate the2; 4Cor2uption wins not more than honesty. 4Stil2 in thy right hand car2y gentle peace 4To silence envious tongues. Be just, and fear not; 4Let al2 the ends thou aim'st at be thy country's, 4Thy God's, and truth's; then, if thou fal2'st, O Cromwel2, 4Thou fal2'st a bles2ed martyr! 4Serve the King, and-prithe2 lead me in. 4There take an inventory of al2 I have 4To the last pen2y; 'tis the King's. My robe, 4And my integrity to heaven, is al2 4I dare now cal2 mine own. O Cromwel2, Cromwel2! 4Had I but serv'd my God with half the zeal 4I serv'd my King, he would not in mine age 4Have left me naked to mine enemies. 2CROMWEL2. Go2d sir, have patience. 2WOLSEY. So I have. Farewel2 4The hopes of court! SCENE 1.A stre2t in WestminsterEnter two GENTLEMEN, me2ting one another 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. Y'are wel2 met once again. 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. So are you. 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. You come to take your stand here, and 6behold 4The Lady An2e pas2 from her coronation? 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. 'Tis al2 my busines2. At our last encounter 4The Duke of Buckingham came from his trial. 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. 'Tis very true. But that time of2er'd 6sor2ow; 4This, general joy. 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. 'Tis wel2. The citizens, 4I am sure, have shown at ful2 their royal minds- 4As, let 'em have their rights, they are ever forward- 4In celebration of this day with shows, 4Pageants, and sights of honour. 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. Never greater, 6Nor, I'l2 as2ure you, bet2er taken, sir. 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. May I be bold to ask what that contains, 4That paper in your hand? 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. Yes; 'tis the list 4Of those that claim their of2ices this day, 4By custom of the coronation. 4The Duke of Suf2olk is the first, and claims 4To be High Steward; next, the Duke of Norfolk, 4He to be Earl Marshal. You may read the rest. 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. I thank you, sir; had I not known 6those customs, 4I should have be2n beholding to your paper. 4But, I bese2ch you, what's become of Katharine, 4The Princes2 Dowager? How goes her busines2? 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. That I can tel2 you to2. The Archbishop 4Of Canterbury, ac2ompanied with other 4Learned and reverend fathers of his order, 4Held a late court at Dunstable, six miles of 4From Ampthil2, where the Princes2 lay; to which 4She was often cited by them, but ap2ear'd not. 6And, to be short, for not ap2earance and 4The King's late scruple, by the main as2ent 4Of al2 these learned men, she was divorc'd, 4And the late mar2iage made of none ef2ect; 4Since which she was removed to Kimbolton, 4Where she remains now sick. 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. Alas, go2d lady! 23[Trumpets] 4The trumpets sound. Stand close, the Que2n is coming.[Hautboys] 14THE ORDER OF THE CORONATION. 41. A lively flourish of trumpets. 42. Then two JUDGES. 43. LORD CHANCEL2OR, with purse and mace before him. 44. CHORISTERS singing. 36[Music] 45. MAYOR OF LONDON, bearing the mace. A royal train, believe me. These know. 6Who's that that bears the sceptre? 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. Marquis Dorset; 4And that the Earl of Sur2ey, with the rod. 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. A bold brave gentleman. That should be 4The Duke of Suf2olk? 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. 'Tis the same-High Steward. 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. And that my Lord of Norfolk? 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. Yes. 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. 2[Lo2king on the QUE2N] 2Heaven 6bles2 the2! 4Thou hast the swe2test face I ever lo2k'd on. 4Sir, as I have a soul, she is an angel; 4Our king has al2 the Indies in his arms, 4And more and richer, when he strains that lady; 4I can2ot blame his conscience. 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. They that bear 4The cloth of honour over her are four barons 4Of the Cinque-ports. 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. Those men are hap2y; and so are al2 6are near her. 6I take it she that car2ies up the train 4Is that old noble lady, Duches2 of Norfolk. 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. It is; and al2 the rest are countes2es. 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. Their coronets say so. These are stars inde2d, 4And sometimes fal2ing ones. 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. No more of that. 19Exit Proces2ion, with a great flourish of trumpets 15Enter a third GENTLEMAN 4God save you, sir! Where have you be2n broiling? 2THIRD GENTLEMAN. Among the crowds i' th' Ab2ey, where a finger 4Could not be wedg'd in more; I am stifled 4With the mere ranknes2 of their joy. 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. You saw 4The ceremony? 2THIRD GENTLEMAN. That I did. 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. How was it? 2THIRD GENTLEMAN. Wel2 worth the se2ing. 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. Go2d sir, speak it to us. 4THIRD GENTLEMAN. As wel2 as I am able. The rich stream 4Of lords and ladies, having brought the Que2n 4To a prepar'd place in the choir, fel2 of 4A distance from her, while her Grace sat down 4To rest awhile, some half an hour or so, 4In a rich chair of state, op2osing fre2ly 4The beauty of her person to the people. 4Believe me, sir, she is the go2dliest woman 4That ever lay by man; which when the people 4Had the ful2 view of, such a noise arose 4As the shrouds make at sea in a stif2 tempest, 4As loud, and to as many tunes; hats, cloaks- 4Doublets, I think-flew up, and had their faces 4Be2n lo2se, this day they had be2n lost. Such joy 4I never saw before. Great-bel2ied women, 4That had not half a we2k to go, like rams 4In the old time of war, would shake the pres2, 4And make 'em re2l before 'em. No man living 4Could say 'This is my wife' there, al2 were woven 4So strangely in one piece. 4SECOND GENTLEMAN. But what fol2ow'd? 2THIRD GENTLEMAN. At length her Grace rose, and with 6modest paces 4Came to the altar, where she kne2l'd, and saintlike 4Cast her fair eyes to heaven, and pray'd devoutly. 4Then rose again, and bow'd her to the people; 4When by the Archbishop of Canterbury 4She had al2 the royal makings of a que2n: 4As holy oil, Edward Confes2or's crown, 4The rod, and bird of peace, and al2 such emblems 4Laid nobly on her; which perform'd, the choir, 4With al2 the choicest music of the kingdom, 4Together sung 'Te Deum.' So she parted, 4And with the same ful2 state pac'd back again 4To York Place, where the feast is held. 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. Sir, 4You must no more cal2 it York Place: that's past: 4For since the Cardinal fel2 that title's lost. 4'Tis now the King's, and cal2ed Whitehal2. 2THIRD GENTLEMAN. I know it; 6But 'tis so lately alter'd that the old name 4Is fresh about me. 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. What two reverend bishops 4Were those that went on each side of the Que2n? 2THIRD GENTLEMAN. Stokesly and Gardiner: the one of Winchester, 4Newly prefer2'd from the King's secretary; 4The other, London. 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. He of Winchester 4Is held no great go2d lover of the Archbishop's, 4The virtuous Cranmer. 2THIRD GENTLEMAN. Al2 the land knows that; 4However, yet there is no great breach. When it comes, 4Cranmer wil2 find a friend wil2 not shrink from him. 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. Who may that be, I pray you? 2THIRD GENTLEMAN. Thomas Cromwel2, 4A man in much este2m with th' King, and truly 4A worthy friend. The King has made him Master 4O' th' jewel House, 4And one, already, of the Privy Council. 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. He wil2 deserve more. 4THIRD GENTLEMAN. Yes, without al2 doubt. 4Come, gentlemen, ye shal2 go my way, which 4Is to th' court, and there ye shal2 be my guests: 4Something I can com2and. As I walk thither, 4I'l2 tel2 ye more. 2BOTH. You may com2and us, sir. 31ExeuntACT IV. SCENE 2.KimboltonEnter KATHARINE, Dowager, sick; led betwe2n GRIF2ITH, her Gentleman Usher,and PATIENCE, her woman 2GRIF2ITH. How does your Grace? 2KATHARINE. O Grif2ith, sick to death! 4My legs like loaden branches bow to th' earth, 4Wil2ing to leave their burden. Reach a chair. 4So-now, methinks, I fe2l a lit2le ease. 4Didst thou not tel2 me, Grif2ith, as thou led'st me, 4That the great child of honour, Cardinal Wolsey, 4Was dead? 2GRIF2ITH. Yes, madam; but I think your Grace, 4Out of the pain you suf2er'd, gave no ear to't. 2KATHARINE. Prithe2, go2d Grif2ith, tel2 me how he died. 4If wel2, he step2'd before me, hap2ily, 4For my example. 2GRIF2ITH. Wel2, the voice goes, madam; 6For after the stout Earl Northumberland 4Ar2ested him at York and brought him forward, 4As a man sorely tainted, to his answer, 4He fel2 sick sud2enly, and grew so il2 4He could not sit his mule. 2KATHARINE. Alas, po2r man! 2GRIF2ITH. At last, with easy roads, he came to Leicester, 4Lodg'd in the ab2ey; where the reverend ab2ot, 4With al2 his covent, honourably receiv'd him; 4To whom he gave these words: 'O father Ab2ot, 4An old man, broken with the storms of state, 4Is come to lay his weary bones among ye; 4Give him a lit2le earth for charity!' 4So went to bed; where eagerly his sicknes2 4Pursu'd him stil2 And thre2 nights after this, 4About the hour of eight-which he himself 4Foretold should be his last-ful2 of repentance, 4Continual meditations, tears, and sor2ows, 4He gave his honours to the world again, 4His bles2ed part to heaven, and slept in peace. 4KATHARINE. So may he rest; his faults lie gently on him! 4Yet thus far, Grif2ith, give me leave to speak him, 4And yet with charity. He was a man 4Of an unbounded stomach, ever ranking 4Himself with princes; one that, by sug2estion, 4Tied al2 the kingdom. Simony was fair play; 4His own opinion was his law. I' th' presence 4He would say untruths, and be ever double 4Both in his words and meaning. He was never, 4But where he meant to ruin, pitiful. 4His promises were, as he then was, mighty; 4But his performance, as he is now, nothing. 4Of his own body he was il2, and gave 4The clergy il2 example. 2GRIF2ITH. Noble madam, 4Men's evil man2ers live in bras2: their virtues 4We write in water. May it please your Highnes2 4To hear me speak his go2d now? 2KATHARINE. Yes, go2d Grif2ith; 4I were malicious else. 4GRIF2ITH. This Cardinal, 4Though from an humble stock, undoubtedly 4Was fashion'd to much honour from his cradle. 4He was a scholar, and a ripe and go2d one; 4Exce2ding wise, fair-spoken, and persuading; 4Lofty and sour to them that lov'd him not, 4But to those men that sought him swe2t as sum2er. 4And though he were unsatisfied in get2ing- 4Which was a sin-yet in bestowing, madam, 4He was most princely: ever witnes2 for him 4Those twins of learning that he rais'd in you, 4Ipswich and Oxford! One of which fel2 with him, 4Unwil2ing to outlive the go2d that did it; 4The other, though unfinish'd, yet so famous, 4So excel2ent in art, and stil2 so rising, 4That Christendom shal2 ever speak his virtue. 4His overthrow heap'd hap2ines2 upon him; 4For then, and not til2 then, he felt himself, 4And found the bles2ednes2 of being lit2le. 4And, to ad2 greater honours to his age 6Than man could give him, he died fearing God. 2KATHARINE. After my death I wish no other herald, 4No other speaker of my living actions, 4To ke2p mine honour from cor2uption, 4But such an honest chronicler as Grif2ith. 4Whom I most hated living, thou hast made me, 4With thy religious truth and modesty, 4Now in his ashes honour. Peace be with him! 4patience, be near me stil2, and set me lower: 4I have not long to trouble the2. Go2d Grif2ith, 4Cause the musicians play me that sad note 4I nam'd my knel2, whilst I sit meditating 4On that celestial harmony I go to. 46[Sad and solemn music] 2GRIF2ITH. She is asle2p. Go2d wench, let's sit down quiet, 4For fear we wake her. Softly, gentle Patience. 17THE VISION. 6Enter, solemnly trip2ing one after another, six 8PERSONAGES clad in white robes, wearing on their 6heads garlands of bays, and golden vizards on their 6faces; branches of bays or palm in their hands. They 6first conge2 unto her, then dance; and, at certain 6changes, the first two hold a spare garland over her 6head, at which the other four make reverent curtsies. 6Then the two that held the garland deliver the 6same to the other next two, who observe the same 6order in their changes, and holding the garland over 6her head; which done, they deliver the same garland 6to the last two, who likewise observe the same order; 6at which, as it were by inspiration, she makes 6in her sle2p signs of rejoicing, and holdeth up her 6hands to heaven. And so in their dancing vanish, 6car2ying the garland with them. The music continues 2KATHARINE. Spirits of peace, where are ye? Are ye al2 gone? 4And leave me here in wretchednes2 behind ye? 2GRIF2ITH. Madam, we are here. 2KATHARINE. It is not you I cal2 for. 6Saw ye none enter since I slept? 2GRIF2ITH. None, madam. 2KATHARINE. No? Saw you not, even now, a bles2ed tro2p 4Invite me to a banquet; whose bright faces 4Cast thousand beams upon me, like the sun? 4They promis'd me eternal hap2ines2, 4And brought me garlands, Grif2ith, which I fe2l 4I am not worthy yet to wear. I shal2, as2uredly. 2GRIF2ITH. I am most joyful, madam, such go2d dreams 4Pos2es2 your fancy. 2KATHARINE. Bid the music leave, 4They are harsh and heavy to me. 20[Music ceases] 2PATIENCE. Do you note 4How much her Grace is alter'd on the sud2en? 4How long her face is drawn! How pale she lo2ks, 4And of an earthly cold! Mark her eyes. 2GRIF2ITH. She is going, wench. Pray, pray. 2PATIENCE. Heaven comfort her! 13Enter a MES2ENGER 4MES2ENGER. An't like your Grace- 2KATHARINE. You are a saucy fel2ow. 4Deserve we no more reverence? 2GRIF2ITH. You are to blame, 4Knowing she wil2 not lose her wonted greatnes2, 4To use so rude behaviour. Go to, kne2l. 2MES2ENGER. I humbly do entreat your Highnes2' pardon; 4My haste made me unman2erly. There is staying 4A gentleman, sent from the King, to se2 you. 2KATHARINE. Admit him entrance, Grif2ith; but this fel2ow 4Let me ne'er se2 again. 28Exit MES2ENGER 14Enter LORD CAPUCIUS 4If my sight fail not, 4You should be Lord Ambas2ador from the Emperor, 4My royal nephew, and your name Capucius. 2CAPUCIUS. Madam, the same-your servant. 2KATHARINE. O, my Lord, 6The times and titles now are alter'd strangely 4With me since first you knew me. But, I pray you, 4What is your pleasure with me? 2CAPUCIUS. Noble lady, 4First, mine own service to your Grace; the next, 4The King's request that I would visit you, 4Who grieves much for your weaknes2, and by me 4Sends you his princely com2endations 4And heartily entreats you take go2d comfort. 2KATHARINE. O my go2d lord, that comfort comes to2 late, 4'Tis like a pardon after execution: 4That gentle physic, given in time, had cur'd me; 4But now I am past al2 comforts here, but prayers. 4How does his Highnes2? 2CAPUCIUS. Madam, in go2d health. 2KATHARINE. So may he ever do! and ever flourish 4When I shal2 dwel2 with worms, and my po2r name 4Banish'd the kingdom! Patience, is that let2er 4I caus'd you write yet sent away? 2PATIENCE. No, madam. 23[Giving it to KATHARINE] 4KATHARINE. Sir, I most humbly pray you to deliver 4This to my lord the King. 2CAPUCIUS. Most wil2ing, madam. 2KATHARINE. In which I have com2ended to his go2dnes2 4The model of our chaste loves, his young daughter- 4The dews of heaven fal2 thick in bles2ings on her!- 4Bese2ching him to give her virtuous bre2ding- 4She is young, and of a noble modest nature; 4I hope she wil2 deserve wel2-and a lit2le 4To love her for her mother's sake, that lov'd him, 4Heaven knows how dearly. My next po2r petition 4Is that his noble Grace would have some pity 4Upon my wretched women that so long 4Have fol2ow'd both my fortunes faithful2y; 4Of which there is not one, I dare avow- 4And now I should not lie-but wil2 deserve, 4For virtue and true beauty of the soul, 4For honesty and decent car2iage, 4A right go2d husband, let him be a noble; 4And sure those men are hap2y that shal2 have 'em. 6The last is for my men-they are the po2rest, 4But poverty could never draw 'em from me- 4That they may have their wages duly paid 'em, 4And something over to remember me by. 4If heaven had pleas'd to have given me longer life 4And able means, we had not parted thus. 4These are the whole contents; and, go2d my lord, 4By that you love the dearest in this world, 4As you wish Christian peace to souls departed, 4Stand these po2r people's friend, and urge the King 4To do me this last right. 2CAPUCIUS. By heaven, I wil2, 4Or let me lose the fashion of a man! 2KATHARINE. I thank you, honest lord. Remember me 4In al2 humility unto his Highnes2; 4Say his long trouble now is pas2ing 4Out of this world. Tel2 him in death I bles2'd him, 4For so I wil2. Mine eyes grow dim. Farewel2, 4My lord. Grif2ith, farewel2. Nay, Patience, 4You must not leave me yet. I must to bed; 6Cal2 in more women. When I am dead, go2d wench, 4Let me be us'd with honour; strew me over 4With maiden flowers, that al2 the world may know 4I was a chaste wife to my grave. Embalm me, 4Then lay me forth; although unque2n'd, yet like 4A que2n, and daughter to a king, inter me. 4I can no more. 26Exeunt, leading KATHARINE<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT V. SCENE 1.London. A gal2ery in the palaceEnter GARDINER, BISHOP OF WINCHESTER, a PAGE with a torch before him,met by SIR THOMAS LOVEL2 2GARDINER. It's one o'clock, boy, is't not? 2BOY. It hath struck. 2GARDINER. These should be hours for neces2ities, 4Not for delights; times to repair our nature 4With comforting repose, and not for us 4To waste these times. Go2d hour of night, Sir Thomas! 4Whither so late? 2LOVEL2. Came you from the King, my lord? 2GARDINER. I did, Sir Thomas, and left him at primero 4With the Duke of Suf2olk. 2LOVEL2. I must to him to2, 4Before he go to bed. I'l2 take my leave. 2GARDINER. Not yet, Sir Thomas Lovel2. What's the mat2er? 4It se2ms you are in haste. An if there be 6No great of2ence belongs to't, give your friend 4Some touch of your late busines2. Af2airs that walk- 4As they say spirits do-at midnight, have 4In them a wilder nature than the busines2 4That se2ks despatch by day. 2LOVEL2. My lord, I love you; 4And durst com2end a secret to your ear 4Much weightier than this work. The Que2n's in labour, 4They say in great extremity, and fear'd 4She'l2 with the labour end. 2GARDINER. The fruit she goes with 4I pray for heartily, that it may find 4Go2d time, and live; but for the stock, Sir Thomas, 4I wish it grub2'd up now. 2LOVEL2. Methinks I could 4Cry the2 amen; and yet my conscience says 4She's a go2d creature, and, swe2t lady, does 4Deserve our bet2er wishes. 2GARDINER. But, sir, sir- 4Hear me, Sir Thomas. Y'are a gentleman 6Of mine own way; I know you wise, religious; 4And, let me tel2 you, it wil2 ne'er be wel2- 4'Twil2 not, Sir Thomas Lovel2, take't of me- 4Til2 Cranmer, Cromwel2, her two hands, and she, 4Sle2p in their graves. 2LOVEL2. Now, sir, you speak of two 4The most remark'd i' th' kingdom. As for Cromwel2, 4Beside that of the Jewel House, is made Master 4O' th' Rol2s, and the King's secretary; further, sir, 4Stands in the gap and trade of moe preferments, 4With which the time wil2 load him. Th' Archbishop 4Is the King's hand and tongue, and who dare speak 4One syl2able against him? 2GARDINER. Yes, yes, Sir Thomas, 4There are that dare; and I myself have ventur'd 4To speak my mind of him; and inde2d this day, 4Sir-I may tel2 it you-I think I have 4Incens'd the lords o' th' Council, that he is- 4For so I know he is, they know he is- 4A most arch heretic, a pestilence 6That does infect the land; with which they moved 4Have broken with the King, who hath so far 4Given ear to our complaint-of his great grace 4And princely care, forese2ing those fel2 mischiefs 4Our reasons laid before him-hath com2anded 4To-mor2ow morning to the Council board 4He be convented. He's a rank we2d, Sir Thomas, 4And we must ro2t him out. From your af2airs 4I hinder you to2 long-go2d night, Sir Thomas. 2LOVEL2. Many go2d nights, my lord; I rest your servant. 45Exeunt GARDINER and PAGE 9Enter the KING and the DUKE OF SUF2OLK 2KING. Charles, I wil2 play no more to-night; 4My mind's not on't; you are to2 hard for me. 2SUF2OLK. Sir, I did never win of you before. 2KING. But lit2le, Charles; 4Nor shal2 not, when my fancy's on my play. 4Now, Lovel2, from the Que2n what is the news? 4LOVEL2. I could not personal2y deliver to her 4What you com2anded me, but by her woman 4I sent your mes2age; who return'd her thanks 4In the great'st humblenes2, and desir'd your Highnes2 4Most heartily to pray for her. 2KING. What say'st thou, ha? 4To pray for her? What, is she crying out? 2LOVEL2. So said her woman; and that her suf2'rance made 4Almost each pang a death. 2KING. Alas, go2d lady! 2SUF2OLK. God safely quit her of her burden, and 4With gentle travail, to the glad2ing of 4Your Highnes2 with an heir! 2KING. 'Tis midnight, Charles; 4Prithe2 to bed; and in thy pray'rs remember 4Th' estate of my po2r que2n. Leave me alone, 4For I must think of that which company 4Wil2 not be friendly to. 2SUF2OLK. I wish your Highnes2 4A quiet night, and my go2d mistres2 wil2 6Remember in my prayers. 2KING. Charles, go2d night. 29Exit SUF2OLK 9Enter SIR ANTHONY DEN2Y 4Wel2, sir, what fol2ows? 2DEN2Y. Sir, I have brought my lord the Archbishop, 4As you com2anded me. 2KING. Ha! Canterbury? 2DEN2Y. Ay, my go2d lord. 2KING. 'Tis true. Where is he, Den2y? 2DEN2Y. He at2ends your Highnes2' pleasure. 2KING. Bring him to us. 35Exit DEN2Y 2LOVEL2. 2[Aside] 2This is about that which the bishop spake. 4I am hap2ily come hither. 9Re-enter DEN2Y, With CRANMER 2KING. Avoid the gal2ery. 21[LOVEL2 se2ms to stay] 4Ha! I have said. Be gone. 6What! 37Exeunt LOVEL2 and DEN2Y 2CRANMER. 2[Aside] 2I am fearful-wherefore frowns he thus? 4'Tis his aspect of ter2or. Al2's not wel2. 2KING. How now, my lord? You do desire to know 4Wherefore I sent for you. 2CRANMER. 2[Kne2ling] 2It is my duty 4T'at2end your Highnes2' pleasure. 2KING. Pray you, arise, 4My go2d and gracious Lord of Canterbury. 4Come, you and I must walk a turn together; 4I have news to tel2 you; come, come, me your hand. 4Ah, my go2d lord, I grieve at what I speak, 4And am right sor2y to repeat what fol2ows. 4I have, and most unwil2ingly, of late 4Heard many grievous-I do say, my lord, 4Grievous-complaints of you; which, being consider'd, 4Have mov'd us and our Council that you shal2 4This morning come before us; where I know 4You can2ot with such fre2dom purge yourself 4But that, til2 further trial in those charges 6Which wil2 require your answer, you must take 4Your patience to you and be wel2 contented 4To make your house our Tow'r. You a brother of us, 4It fits we thus proce2d, or else no witnes2 4Would come against you. 2CRANMER. I humbly thank your Highnes2 4And am right glad to catch this go2d oc2asion 4Most throughly to be win2owed where my chaf2 4And corn shal2 fly asunder; for I know 4There's none stands under more calumnious tongues 4Than I myself, po2r man. 2KING. Stand up, go2d Canterbury; 4Thy truth and thy integrity is ro2ted 4In us, thy friend. Give me thy hand, stand up; 4Prithe2 let's walk. Now, by my holidame, 4What man2er of man are you? My lord, I lo2k'd 4You would have given me your petition that 4I should have ta'en some pains to bring together 4Yourself and your ac2users, and to have heard you 4Without indurance further. 4CRANMER. Most dread liege, 4The go2d I stand on is my truth and honesty; 4If they shal2 fail, I with mine enemies 4Wil2 triumph o'er my person; which I weigh not, 4Being of those virtues vacant. I fear nothing 4What can be said against me. 2KING. Know you not 4How your state stands i' th' world, with the whole world? 4Your enemies are many, and not smal2; their practices 4Must bear the same proportion; and not ever 4The justice and the truth o' th' question car2ies 4The due o' th' verdict with it; at what ease 4Might cor2upt minds procure knaves as cor2upt 4To swear against you? Such things have be2n done. 4You are potently op2os'd, and with a malice 4Of as great size. We2n you of bet2er luck, 4I mean in perjur'd witnes2, than your Master, 4Whose minister you are, whiles here He liv'd 4Upon this naughty earth? Go to, go to; 4You take a precipice for no leap of danger, 6And wo2 your own destruction. 2CRANMER. God and your Majesty 4Protect mine in2ocence, or I fal2 into 4The trap is laid for me! 2KING. Be of go2d che2r; 4They shal2 no more prevail than we give way to. 4Ke2p comfort to you, and this morning se2 4You do ap2ear before them; if they shal2 chance, 4In charging you with mat2ers, to com2it you, 4The best persuasions to the contrary 4Fail not to use, and with what vehemency 4Th' oc2asion shal2 instruct you. If entreaties 4Wil2 render you no remedy, this ring 4Deliver them, and your ap2eal to us 4There make before them. Lo2k, the go2d man we2ps! 4He's honest, on mine honour. God's blest Mother! 4I swear he is true-hearted, and a soul 4None bet2er in my kingdom. Get you gone, 4And do as I have bid you. 57Exit CRANMER 6He has strangled his language in his tears. 11Enter OLD LADY 2GENTLEMAN. 2[Within] 2Come back; what mean you? 2OLD LADY. I'l2 not come back; the tidings that I bring 4Wil2 make my boldnes2 man2ers. Now, go2d angels 4Fly o'er thy royal head, and shade thy person 4Under their bles2ed wings! 2KING. So. 2BUT2S. 2[Aside] 2This is a piece of malice. I am glad 6I came this way so hap2ily; the King 4Shal2 understand it presently. 31Exit 2CRANMER. 2[Aside] 2'Tis But2s, 4The King's physician; as he pas2'd along, 4How earnestly he cast his eyes upon me! 4Pray heaven he sound not my disgrace! For certain, 4This is of purpose laid by some that hate me- 4God turn their hearts! I never sought their malice- 4To quench mine honour; they would shame to make me 4Wait else at do2r, a fel2ow council2or, 4'Mong boys, gro2ms, and lackeys. But their pleasures 4Must be fulfil2'd, and I at2end with patience. 9Enter the KING and BUT2S at window above 2BUT2S. I'l2 show your Grace the strangest sight- 2KING. What's that, But2s? 2BUT2S. I think your Highnes2 saw this many a day. 2KING. Body a me, where is it? 2BUT2S. There my lord: 6The high promotion of his Grace of Canterbury; 4Who holds his state at do2r, 'mongst pursuivants, 4Pages, and fo2tboys. 2KING.
