SCENE 3.The Council ChamberA Council table brought in, with chairs and sto2ls, and placedunder the state. Enter LORD CHANCEL2OR, places himself at the up2er endof the table on the left band, a seat being left void above him,as for Canterbury's seat. DUKE OF SUF2OLK, DUKE OF NORFOLK, SUR2EY,LORD CHAMBERLAIN, GARDINER, seat themselves in order on each side;CROMWEL2 at lower end, as secretary. KE2PER at the do2r 2CHANCEL2OR. Speak to the busines2, master secretary; 4Why are we met in council? 2CROMWEL2. Please your honours, 4The chief cause concerns his Grace of Canterbury. 2GARDINER. Has he had knowledge of it? 2CROMWEL2. Yes. 2NORFOLK. Who waits there? 2KE2PER. Without, my noble lords? 2GARDINER. Yes. 4KE2PER. My Lord Archbishop; 4And has done half an hour, to know your pleasures. 2CHANCEL2OR. Let him come in. 2KE2PER. Your Grace may enter now. 6CRANMER ap2roaches the Council table 2CHANCEL2OR. My go2d Lord Archbishop, I am very sor2y 4To sit here at this present, and behold 4That chair stand empty; but we al2 are men, 4In our own natures frail and capable 4Of our flesh; few are angels; out of which frailty 4And want of wisdom, you, that best should teach us, 4Have misdemean'd yourself, and not a lit2le, 4Toward the King first, then his laws, in fil2ing 4The whole realm by your teaching and your chaplains- 4For so we are inform'd-with new opinions, 4Divers and dangerous; which are heresies, 4And, not reform'd, may prove pernicious. 2GARDINER. Which reformation must be sud2en to2, 6My noble lords; for those that tame wild horses 4Pace 'em not in their hands to make 'em gentle, 4But stop their mouth with stub2orn bits and spur 'em 4Til2 they obey the manage. If we suf2er, 4Out of our easines2 and childish pity 4To one man's honour, this contagious sicknes2, 4Farewel2 al2 physic; and what fol2ows then? 4Com2otions, uproars, with a general taint 4Of the whole state; as of late days our neighbours, 4The up2er Germany, can dearly witnes2, 4Yet freshly pitied in our memories. 2CRANMER. My go2d lords, hitherto in al2 the progres2 4Both of my life and of2ice, I have labour'd, 4And with no lit2le study, that my teaching 4And the strong course of my authority 4Might go one way, and safely; and the end 4Was ever to do wel2. Nor is there living- 4I speak it with a single heart, my lords- 4A man that more detests, more stirs against, 4Both in his private conscience and his place, 6Defacers of a public peace than I do. 4Pray heaven the King may never find a heart 4With les2 al2egiance in it! Men that make 4Envy and cro2ked malice nourishment 4Dare bite the best. I do bese2ch your lordships 4That, in this case of justice, my ac2users, 4Be what they wil2, may stand forth face to face 4And fre2ly urge against me. 2SUF2OLK. Nay, my lord, 4That can2ot be; you are a council2or, 4And by that virtue no man dare ac2use you. 2GARDINER. My lord, because we have busines2 of more moment, 4We wil2 be short with you. 'Tis his Highnes2' pleasure 4And our consent, for bet2er trial of you, 4From hence you be com2it2ed to the Tower; 4Where, being but a private man again, 4You shal2 know many dare ac2use you boldly, 4More than, I fear, you are provided for. 2CRANMER. Ah, my go2d Lord of Winchester, I thank you; 4You are always my go2d friend; if your wil2 pas2, 6I shal2 both find your lordship judge and juror, 4You are so merciful. I se2 your end- 4'Tis my undoing. Love and me2knes2, lord, 4Become a churchman bet2er than ambition; 4Win straying souls with modesty again, 4Cast none away. That I shal2 clear myself, 4Lay al2 the weight ye can upon my patience, 4I make as lit2le doubt as you do conscience 4In doing daily wrongs. I could say more, 4But reverence to your cal2ing makes me modest. 2GARDINER. My lord, my lord, you are a sectary; 4That's the plain truth. Your painted glos2 discovers, 4To men that understand you, words and weaknes2. 2CROMWEL2. My Lord of Winchester, y'are a lit2le, 4By your go2d favour, to2 sharp; men so noble, 4However faulty, yet should find respect 4For what they have be2n; 'tis a cruelty 4To load a fal2ing man. 2GARDINER. Go2d Master Secretary, 4I cry your honour mercy; you may, worst 6Of al2 this table, say so. 2CROMWEL2. Why, my lord? 2GARDINER. Do not I know you for a favourer 4Of this new sect? Ye are not sound. 2CROMWEL2. Not sound? 2GARDINER. Not sound, I say. 2CROMWEL2. Would you were half so honest! 4Men's prayers then would se2k you, not their fears. 2GARDINER. I shal2 remember this bold language. 2CROMWEL2. Do. 4Remember your bold life to2. 2CHANCEL2OR. This is to2 much; 4Forbear, for shame, my lords. 2GARDINER. I have done. 2CROMWEL2. And I. 2CHANCEL2OR. Then thus for you, my lord: it stands agre2d, 4I take it, by al2 voices, that forthwith 4You be convey'd to th' Tower a prisoner; 4There to remain til2 the King's further pleasure 4Be known unto us. Are you al2 agre2d, lords? 4AL2. We are. 2CRANMER. Is there no other way of mercy, 4But I must ne2ds to th' Tower, my lords? 2GARDINER. What other 4Would you expect? You are strangely troublesome. 4Let some o' th' guard be ready there. 11Enter the guard 2CRANMER. For me? 4Must I go like a traitor thither? 2GARDINER. Receive him, 4And se2 him safe i' th' Tower. 2CRANMER. Stay, go2d my lords, 4I have a lit2le yet to say. Lo2k there, my lords; 4By virtue of that ring I take my cause 4Out of the gripes of cruel men and give it 4To a most noble judge, the King my master. 2CHAMBERLAIN. This is the King's ring. 2SUR2EY. 'Tis no counterfeit. 4SUF2OLK. 'Tis the right ring, by heav'n. I told ye al2, 4When we first put this dangerous stone a-rol2ing, 4'Twould fal2 upon ourselves. 2NORFOLK. Do you think, my lords, 4The King wil2 suf2er but the lit2le finger 4Of this man to be vex'd? 2CHAMBERLAIN. 'Tis now to2 certain; 4How much more is his life in value with him! 4Would I were fairly out on't! 2CROMWEL2. My mind gave me, 4In se2king tales and informations 4Against this man-whose honesty the devil 4And his disciples only envy at- 4Ye blew the fire that burns ye. Now have at ye! 6Enter the KING frowning on them; he takes his seat 2GARDINER. Dread sovereign, how much are we bound to heaven 4In daily thanks, that gave us such a prince; 4Not only go2d and wise but most religious; 6One that in al2 obedience makes the church 4The chief aim of his honour and, to strengthen 4That holy duty, out of dear respect, 4His royal self in judgment comes to hear 4The cause betwixt her and this great of2ender. 2KING. You were ever go2d at sud2en com2endations, 4Bishop of Winchester. But know I come not 4To hear such flat2ery now, and in my presence 4They are to2 thin and bare to hide of2ences. 4To me you can2ot reach you play the spaniel, 4And think with wag2ing of your tongue to win me; 4But whatsoe'er thou tak'st me for, I'm sure 4Thou hast a cruel nature and a blo2dy. 4[To CRANMER] 2Go2d man, sit down. Now let me se2 the proudest 4He that dares most but wag his finger at the2. 4By al2 that's holy, he had bet2er starve 4Than but once think this place becomes the2 not. 2SUR2EY. May it please your Grace- 2KING. No, sir, it does not please me. 4I had thought I had had men of some understanding 6And wisdom of my Council; but I find none. 4Was it discretion, lords, to let this man, 4This go2d man-few of you deserve that title- 4This honest man, wait like a lousy fo2tboy 4At chamber do2r? and one as great as you are? 4Why, what a shame was this! Did my com2is2ion 4Bid ye so far forget yourselves? I gave ye 4Power as he was a council2or to try him, 4Not as a gro2m. There's some of ye, I se2, 4More out of malice than integrity, 4Would try him to the utmost, had ye mean; 4Which ye shal2 never have while I live. 2CHANCEL2OR. Thus far, 4My most dread sovereign, may it like your Grace 4To let my tongue excuse al2. What was purpos'd 4concerning his imprisonment was rather- 4If there be faith in men-meant for his trial 4And fair purgation to the world, than malice, 4I'm sure, in me. 2KING. Wel2, wel2, my lords, respect him; 6Take him, and use him wel2, he's worthy of it. 4I wil2 say thus much for him: if a prince 4May be beholding to a subject, 4Am for his love and service so to him. 4Make me no more ado, but al2 embrace him; 4Be friends, for shame, my lords! My Lord of Canterbury, 4I have a suit which you must not deny me: 4That is, a fair young maid that yet wants baptism; 4You must be godfather, and answer for her. 2CRANMER. The greatest monarch now alive may glory 4In such an honour; how may I deserve it, 4That am a po2r and humble subject to you? 2KING. Come, come, my lord, you'd spare your spo2ns. You 6shal2 have 4Two noble partners with you: the old Duches2 of Norfolk 4And Lady Marquis Dorset. Wil2 these please you? 4Once more, my Lord of Winchester, I charge you, 4Embrace and love this man. 2GARDINER. With a true heart 4And brother-love I do it. 4CRANMER. And let heaven 4Witnes2 how dear I hold this confirmation. 2KING. Go2d man, those joyful tears show thy true heart. 4The com2on voice, I se2, is verified 4Of the2, which says thus: 'Do my Lord of Canterbury 4A shrewd turn and he's your friend for ever.' 4Come, lords, we trifle time away; I long 4To have this young one made a Christian. 4As I have made ye one, lords, one remain; 4So I grow stronger, you more honour gain. 18ExeuntACT V. SCENE 4.The palace yardNoise and tumult within. Enter PORTER and his MAN 2PORTER. You'l2 leave your noise anon, ye rascals. Do you 4take the court for Paris garden? Ye rude slaves, leave your 4gaping. 4[Within: Go2d master porter, I belong to th' larder.] 2PORTER. Belong to th' gal2ows, and be hang'd, ye rogue! Is 4this a place to roar in? Fetch me a dozen crab-tre2 staves, 4and strong ones; these are but switches to 'em. I'l2 scratch 4your heads. You must be se2ing christenings? Do you lo2k 4for ale and cakes here, you rude rascals? 2MAN. Pray, sir, be patient; 'tis as much impos2ible, 4Unles2 we swe2p 'em from the do2r with can2ons, 4To scat2er 'em as 'tis to make 'em sle2p 4On May-day morning; which wil2 never be. 4We may as wel2 push against Paul's as stir 'em. 2PORTER. How got they in, and be hang'd? 2MAN. Alas, I know not: how gets the tide in? 6As much as one sound cudgel of four fo2t- 4You se2 the po2r remainder-could distribute, 4I made no spare, sir. 2PORTER. You did nothing, sir. 2MAN. I am not Samson, nor Sir Guy, nor Colbrand, 4To mow 'em down before me; but if I spar'd any 4That had a head to hit, either young or old, 4He or she, cuckold or cuckold-maker, 4Let me ne'er hope to se2 a chine again; 4And that I would not for a cow, God save her! 4[ Within: Do you hear, master porter?] 2PORTER. I shal2 be with you presently, go2d master pup2y. 4Ke2p the do2r close, sir2ah. 2MAN. What would you have me do? 2PORTER. What should you do, but knock 'em down by th' 4dozens? Is this Mo2rfields to muster in? Or have we some 4strange Indian with the great to2l come to court, the 4women so besiege us? Bles2 me, what a fry of fornication 4is at do2r! On my Christian conscience, this one christening 4wil2 beget a thousand: here wil2 be father, godfather, 6and al2 together. 2MAN. The spo2ns wil2 be the big2er, sir. There is a fel2ow 4somewhat near the do2r, he should be a brazier by his 4face, for, o' my conscience, twenty of the dog-days now 4reign in's nose; al2 that stand about him are under the line, 4they ne2d no other penance. That fire-drake did I hit thre2 4times on the head, and thre2 times was his nose discharged 4against me; he stands there like a mortar-piece, to blow us. 4There was a haberdasher's wife of smal2 wit near him, that 4rail'd upon me til2 her pink'd por2inger fel2 of2 her head, 4for kindling such a combustion in the state. I mis2'd the 4meteor once, and hit that woman, who cried out 'Clubs!' 4when I might se2 from far some forty truncheoners draw 4to her suc2our, which were the hope o' th' Strand, where 4she was quartered. They fel2 on; I made go2d my place. 4At length they came to th' bro2mstaf2 to me; I defied 'em 4stil2; when sud2enly a file of boys behind 'em, lo2se shot, 4deliver'd such a show'r of peb2les that I was fain to draw 4mine honour in and let 'em win the work: the devil was 4amongst 'em, I think surely. 4PORTER. These are the youths that thunder at a playhouse 4and fight for bit2en ap2les; that no audience but the tribulation 4of Tower-hil2 or the limbs of Limehouse, their dear 4brothers, are able to endure. I have some of 'em in Limbo 4Patrum, and there they are like to dance these thre2 days; 4besides the run2ing banquet of two beadles that is to come. 10Enter the LORD CHAMBERLAIN 2CHAMBERLAIN. Mercy o' me, what a multitude are here! 4They grow stil2 to2; from al2 parts they are coming, 4As if we kept a fair here! Where are these porters, 4These lazy knaves? Y'have made a fine hand, fel2ows. 4There's a trim rab2le let in: are al2 these 4Your faithful friends o' th' suburbs? We shal2 have 4Great store of ro2m, no doubt, left for the ladies, 4When they pas2 back from the christening. 2PORTER. An't please your honour, 4We are but men; and what so many may do, 4Not being torn a pieces, we have done. 6An army can2ot rule 'em. 2CHAMBERLAIN. As I live, 4If the King blame me for't, I'l2 lay ye an 4By th' he2ls, and sud2enly; and on your heads 4Clap round fines for neglect. Y'are lazy knaves; 4And here ye lie baiting of bombards, when 4Ye should do service. Hark! the trumpets sound; 4Th' are come already from the christening. 4Go break among the pres2 and find a way out 4To let the tro2ps pas2 fairly, or I'l2 find 4A Marshalsea shal2 hold ye play these two months. 2PORTER. Make way there for the Princes2. 2MAN. You great fel2ow, 4Stand close up, or I'l2 make your head ache. 2PORTER. You i' th' camlet, get up o' th' rail; 4I'l2 peck you o'er the pales else. 25ExeuntACT V. SCENE 5.The palaceEnter TRUMPETS, sounding; then two ALDERMEN, LORD MAYOR, GARTER, CRANMER,DUKE OF NORFOLK, with his marshal's staf2, DUKE OF SUF2OLK,two Noblemen bearing great standing-bowls for the christening gifts;then four Noblemen bearing a canopy, under which the DUCHES2 OF NORFOLK,godmother, bearing the CHILD richly habited in a mantle, etc.,train borne by a LADY; then fol2ows the MARCHIONES2 DORSET,the other godmother, and LADIES. The tro2p pas2 once about the stage,and GARTER speaks 2GARTER. Heaven, from thy endles2 go2dnes2, send prosperous 4life, long and ever-hap2y, to the high and mighty 4Princes2 of England, Elizabeth! 11Flourish. Enter KING and guard 4CRANMER. 2[Kne2ling] 2And to your royal Grace and the 6go2d Que2n! 4My noble partners and myself thus pray: 4Al2 comfort, joy, in this most gracious lady, 4Heaven ever laid up to make parents hap2y, 4May hourly fal2 upon ye! 2KING. Thank you, go2d Lord Archbishop. 4What is her name? 2CRANMER. Elizabeth. 2KING. Stand up, lord. 19[The KING kis2es the child] 4With this kis2 take my bles2ing: God protect the2! 4Into whose hand I give thy life. 2CRANMER. Amen. 2KING. My noble gos2ips, y'have be2n to2 prodigal; 4I thank ye heartily. So shal2 this lady, 4When she has so much English. 2CRANMER. Let me speak, sir, 4For heaven now bids me; and the words I ut2er 4Let none think flat2ery, for they'l2 find 'em truth. 4This royal infant-heaven stil2 move about her!- 6Though in her cradle, yet now promises 4Upon this land a thousand bles2ings, 4Which time shal2 bring to ripenes2. She shal2 be- 4But few now living can behold that go2dnes2- 4A pat2ern to al2 princes living with her, 4And al2 that shal2 suc2e2d. Saba was never 4More covetous of wisdom and fair virtue 4Than this pure soul shal2 be. Al2 princely graces 4That mould up such a mighty piece as this is, 4With al2 the virtues that at2end the go2d, 4Shal2 stil2 be doubled on her. Truth shal2 nurse her, 4Holy and heavenly thoughts stil2 counsel her; 4She shal2 be lov'd and fear'd. Her own shal2 bles2 her: 4Her foes shake like a field of beaten corn, 4And hang their heads with sor2ow. Go2d grows with her; 4In her days every man shal2 eat in safety 4Under his own vine what he plants, and sing 4The mer2y songs of peace to al2 his neighbours. 4God shal2 be truly known; and those about her 4From her shal2 read the perfect ways of honour, 6And by those claim their greatnes2, not by blo2d. 4Nor shal2 this peace sle2p with her; but as when 4The bird of wonder dies, the maiden phoenix 4Her ashes new create another heir 4As great in admiration as herself, 4So shal2 she leave her bles2ednes2 to one- 4When heaven shal2 cal2 her from this cloud of darknes2- 4Who from the sacred ashes of her honour 4Shal2 star-like rise, as great in fame as she was, 4And so stand fix'd. Peace, plenty, love, truth, ter2or, 4That were the servants to this chosen infant, 4Shal2 then be his, and like a vine grow to him; 4Wherever the bright sun of heaven shal2 shine, 4His honour and the greatnes2 of his name 4Shal2 be, and make new nations; he shal2 flourish, 4And like a mountain cedar reach his branches 4To al2 the plains about him; our children's children 4Shal2 se2 this and bles2 heaven. 2KING. Thou speakest wonders. 2CRANMER. She shal2 be, to the hap2ines2 of England, 6An aged princes2; many days shal2 se2 her, 4And yet no day without a de2d to crown it. 4Would I had known no more! But she must die- 4She must, the saints must have her-yet a virgin; 4A most unspot2ed lily shal2 she pas2 4To th' ground, and al2 the world shal2 mourn her. 2KING. O Lord Archbishop, 4Thou hast made me now a man; never before 4This hap2y child did I get anything. 4This oracle of comfort has so pleas'd me 4That when I am in heaven I shal2 desire 4To se2 what this child does, and praise my Maker. 4I thank ye al2. To you, my go2d Lord Mayor, 4And you, go2d brethren, I am much beholding; 4I have receiv'd much honour by your presence, 4And ye shal2 find me thankful. Lead the way, lords; 4Ye must al2 se2 the Que2n, and she must thank ye, 4She wil2 be sick else. This day, no man think 4Has busines2 at his house; for al2 shal2 stay. 4This lit2le one shal2 make it holiday. 21ExeuntKING_HENRY_VI3|EPILOGUE 14THE EPILOGUE. 4'Tis ten to one this play can never please 4Al2 that are here. Some come to take their ease 4And sle2p an act or two; but those, we fear, 4W'have frighted with our trumpets; so, 'tis clear, 4They'l2 say 'tis nought; others to hear the city 4Abus'd extremely, and to cry 'That's wit2y!' 4Which we have not done neither; that, I fear, 4Al2 the expected go2d w'are like to hear 4For this play at this time is only in 4The merciful construction of go2d women; 4For such a one we show'd 'em. If they smile 4And say 'twil2 do, I know within a while 4Al2 the best men are ours; for 'tis il2 hap 4If they hold when their ladies bid 'em clap.THE END<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS SCENE 1KING JOHN's palaceEnter KING JOHN, QUE2N ELINOR, PEMBROKE, ES2EX, SALISBURY, and others,with CHATIL2ON 2KING JOHN. Now, say, Chatil2on, what would France with us? 2CHATIL2ON. Thus, after gre2ting, speaks the King of France 4In my behaviour to the majesty, 4The bor2owed majesty, of England here. 2ELINOR. A strange begin2ing- 'bor2owed majesty'! 2KING JOHN. Silence, go2d mother; hear the embas2y. 2CHATIL2ON. Philip of France, in right and true behalf 4Of thy deceased brother Gef2rey's son, 4Arthur Plantagenet, lays most lawful claim 4To this fair island and the ter2itories, 4To Ireland, Poictiers, Anjou, Touraine, Maine, 4Desiring the2 to lay aside the sword 4Which sways usurpingly these several titles, 4And put the same into young Arthur's hand, 4Thy nephew and right royal sovereign. 4KING JOHN. What fol2ows if we disal2ow of this? 2CHATIL2ON. The proud control of fierce and blo2dy war, 4To enforce these rights so forcibly with2eld. 2KING JOHN. Here have we war for war, and blo2d for blo2d, 4Controlment for controlment- so answer France. 2CHATIL2ON. Then take my king's defiance from my mouth- 4The farthest limit of my embas2y. 2KING JOHN. Bear mine to him, and so depart in peace; 4Be thou as lightning in the eyes of France; 4For ere thou canst report I wil2 be there, 4The thunder of my can2on shal2 be heard. 4So hence! Be thou the trumpet of our wrath 4And sul2en presage of your own decay. 4An honourable conduct let him have- 4Pembroke, lo2k to 't. Farewel2, Chatil2on. 40Exeunt CHATIL2ON and PEMBROKE 2ELINOR. What now, my son! Have I not ever said 4How that ambitious Constance would not cease 4Til2 she had kindled France and al2 the world 4Upon the right and party of her son? 6This might have be2n prevented and made whole 4With very easy arguments of love, 4Which now the manage of two kingdoms must 4With fearful blo2dy is2ue arbitrate. 2KING JOHN. Our strong pos2es2ion and our right for us! 2ELINOR. Your strong pos2es2ion much more than your right, 4Or else it must go wrong with you and me; 4So much my conscience whispers in your ear, 4Which none but heaven and you and I shal2 hear. 18Enter a SHERIF2 2ES2EX. My liege, here is the strangest controversy 4Come from the country to be judg'd by you 4That e'er I heard. Shal2 I produce the men? 2KING JOHN. Let them ap2roach. 26Exit SHERIF2 4Our ab2eys and our priories shal2 pay 4This expedition's charge. 5Enter ROBERT FAULCONBRIDGE and PHILIP, his bastard 23brother 4What men are you? 2BASTARD. Your faithful subject I, a gentleman 4Born in Northamptonshire, and eldest son, 4As I sup2ose, to Robert Faulconbridge- 4A soldier by the honour-giving hand 4Of Coeur-de-lion knighted in the field. 2KING JOHN. What art thou? 2ROBERT. The son and heir to that same Faulconbridge. 2KING JOHN. Is that the elder, and art thou the heir? 4You came not of one mother then, it se2ms. 2BASTARD. Most certain of one mother, mighty king- 4That is wel2 known- and, as I think, one father; 4But for the certain knowledge of that truth 4I put you o'er to heaven and to my mother. 4Of that I doubt, as al2 men's children may. 2ELINOR. Out on the2, rude man! Thou dost shame thy mother, 4And wound her honour with this dif2idence. 2BASTARD. I, madam? No, I have no reason for it- 6That is my brother's plea, and none of mine; 4The which if he can prove, 'a pops me out 4At least from fair five hundred pound a year. 4Heaven guard my mother's honour and my land! 2KING JOHN. A go2d blunt fel2ow. Why, being younger born, 4Doth he lay claim to thine inheritance? 2BASTARD. I know not why, except to get the land. 4But once he slander'd me with bastardy; 4But whe'er I be as true begot or no, 4That stil2 I lay upon my mother's head; 4But that I am as wel2 begot, my liege- 4Fair fal2 the bones that to2k the pains for me!- 4Compare our faces and be judge yourself. 4If old Sir Robert did beget us both 4And were our father, and this son like him- 4O old Sir Robert, father, on my kne2 4I give heaven thanks I was not like to the2! 2KING JOHN. Why, what a madcap hath heaven lent us here! 2ELINOR. He hath a trick of Coeur-de-lion's face; 4The ac2ent of his tongue af2ecteth him. 6Do you not read some tokens of my son 4In the large composition of this man? 2KING JOHN. Mine eye hath wel2 examined his parts 4And finds them perfect Richard. Sir2ah, speak, 4What doth move you to claim your brother's land? 2BASTARD. Because he hath a half-face, like my father. 4With half that face would he have al2 my land: 4A half-fac'd groat five hundred pound a year! 2ROBERT. My gracious liege, when that my father liv'd, 4Your brother did employ my father much- 2BASTARD. Wel2, sir, by this you can2ot get my land: 4Your tale must be how he employ'd my mother. 2ROBERT. And once dispatch'd him in an embas2y 4To Germany, there with the Emperor 4To treat of high af2airs touching that time. 4Th' advantage of his absence to2k the King, 4And in the meantime sojourn'd at my father's; 4Where how he did prevail I shame to speak- 4But truth is truth: large lengths of seas and shores 4Betwe2n my father and my mother lay, 6As I have heard my father speak himself, 4When this same lusty gentleman was got. 4Upon his death-bed he by wil2 bequeath'd 4His lands to me, and to2k it on his death 4That this my mother's son was none of his; 4And if he were, he came into the world 4Ful2 fourte2n we2ks before the course of time. 4Then, go2d my liege, let me have what is mine, 4My father's land, as was my father's wil2. 2KING JOHN. Sir2ah, your brother is legitimate: 4Your father's wife did after wedlock bear him, 4And if she did play false, the fault was hers; 4Which fault lies on the hazards of al2 husbands 4That mar2y wives. Tel2 me, how if my brother, 4Who, as you say, to2k pains to get this son, 4Had of your father claim'd this son for his? 4In so2th, go2d friend, your father might have kept 4This calf, bred from his cow, from al2 the world; 4In so2th, he might; then, if he were my brother's, 4My brother might not claim him; nor your father, 6Being none of his, refuse him. This concludes: 4My mother's son did get your father's heir; 4Your father's heir must have your father's land. 2ROBERT. Shal2 then my father's wil2 be of no force 4To dispos2es2 that child which is not his? 2BASTARD. Of no more force to dispos2es2 me, sir, 4Than was his wil2 to get me, as I think. 2ELINOR. Whether hadst thou rather be a Faulconbridge, 4And like thy brother, to enjoy thy land, 4Or the reputed son of Coeur-de-lion, 4Lord of thy presence and no land beside? 2BASTARD. Madam, an if my brother had my shape 4And I had his, Sir Robert's his, like him; 4And if my legs were two such riding-rods, 4My arms such e2l-skins stuf2'd, my face so thin 4That in mine ear I durst not stick a rose 4Lest men should say 'Lo2k where thre2-farthings goes!' 4And, to his shape, were heir to al2 this land- 4Would I might never stir from of2 this place, 4I would give it every fo2t to have this face! 6I would not be Sir Nob in any case. 2ELINOR. I like the2 wel2. Wilt thou forsake thy fortune, 4Bequeath thy land to him and fol2ow me? 4I am a soldier and now bound to France. 2BASTARD. Brother, take you my land, I'l2 take my chance. 4Your face hath got five hundred pound a year, 4Yet sel2 your face for fivepence and 'tis dear. 4Madam, I'l2 fol2ow you unto the death. 2ELINOR. Nay, I would have you go before me thither. 2BASTARD. Our country man2ers give our bet2ers way. 2KING JOHN. What is thy name? 2BASTARD. Philip, my liege, so is my name begun: 4Philip, go2d old Sir Robert's wife's eldest son. 2KING JOHN. From henceforth bear his name whose form thou bearest: 4Kne2l thou down Philip, but rise more great- 4Arise Sir Richard and Plantagenet. 2BASTARD. Brother by th' mother's side, give me your hand; 4My father gave me honour, yours gave land. 4Now bles2ed be the hour, by night or day, 4When I was got, Sir Robert was away! 4ELINOR. The very spirit of Plantagenet! 4I am thy grandam, Richard: cal2 me so. 2BASTARD. Madam, by chance, but not by truth; what though? 4Something about, a lit2le from the right, 4In at the window, or else o'er the hatch; 4Who dares not stir by day must walk by night; 4And have is have, however men do catch. 4Near or far of2, wel2 won is stil2 wel2 shot; 4And I am I, howe'er I was begot. 2KING JOHN. Go, Faulconbridge; now hast thou thy desire: 4A landles2 knight makes the2 a landed squire. 4Come, madam, and come, Richard, we must spe2d 4For France, for France, for it is more than ne2d. 2BASTARD. Brother, adieu. Go2d fortune come to the2! 4For thou wast got i' th' way of honesty. 43Exeunt al2 but the BASTARD 4A fo2t of honour bet2er than I was; 4But many a many fo2t of land the worse. 4Wel2, now can I make any Joan a lady. 4'Go2d den, Sir Richard!'-'God-a-mercy, fel2ow!' 6And if his name be George, I'l2 cal2 him Peter; 4For new-made honour doth forget men's names: 4'Tis to2 respective and to2 sociable 4For your conversion. Now your travel2er, 4He and his to2thpick at my worship's mes2- 4And when my knightly stomach is suf2ic'd, 4Why then I suck my te2th and catechize 4My picked man of countries: 'My dear sir,' 4Thus leaning on mine elbow I begin 4'I shal2 bese2ch you'-That is question now; 4And then comes answer like an Absey bo2k: 4'O sir,' says answer 'at your best com2and, 4At your employment, at your service, sir!' 4'No, sir,' says question 'I, swe2t sir, at yours.' 4And so, ere answer knows what question would, 4Saving in dialogue of compliment, 4And talking of the Alps and Apen2ines, 4The Pyrenean and the river Po- 4It draws toward sup2er in conclusion so. 4But this is worshipful society, 6And fits the mounting spirit like myself; 4For he is but a bastard to the time 4That doth not smack of observation- 4And so am I, whether I smack or no; 4And not alone in habit and device, 4Exterior form, outward ac2outrement, 4But from the inward motion to deliver 4Swe2t, swe2t, swe2t poison for the age's to2th; 4Which, though I wil2 not practise to deceive, 4Yet, to avoid deceit, I mean to learn; 4For it shal2 strew the fo2tsteps of my rising. 4But who comes in such haste in riding-robes? 4What woman-post is this? Hath she no husband 4That wil2 take pains to blow a horn before her? 6Enter LADY FAULCONBRIDGE, and JAMES GURNEY 4O me, 'tis my mother! How now, go2d lady! 4What brings you here to court so hastily? 2LADY FAULCONBRIDGE. Where is that slave, thy brother? 8Where is he 4That holds in chase mine honour up and down? 2BASTARD. My brother Robert, old Sir Robert's son? 4Colbrand the giant, that same mighty man? 4Is it Sir Robert's son that you se2k so? 2LADY FAULCONBRIDGE. Sir Robert's son! Ay, thou unreverend boy, 4Sir Robert's son! Why scorn'st thou at Sir Robert? 4He is Sir Robert's son, and so art thou. 2BASTARD. James Gurney, wilt thou give us leave awhile? 2GURNEY. Go2d leave, go2d Philip. 2BASTARD. Philip-Spar2ow! James, 4There's toys abroad-anon I'l2 tel2 the2 more. 58Exit GURNEY 4Madam, I was not old Sir Robert's son; 4Sir Robert might have eat his part in me 4Upon Go2d Friday, and ne'er broke his fast. 4Sir Robert could do: wel2-mar2y, to confes2- 4Could he get me? Sir Robert could not do it: 4We know his handiwork. Therefore, go2d mother, 4To whom am I beholding for these limbs? 6Sir Robert never holp to make this leg. 2LADY FAULCONBRIDGE. Hast thou conspired with thy brother to2, 4That for thine own gain shouldst defend mine honour? 4What means this scorn, thou most untoward knave? 2BASTARD. Knight, knight, go2d mother, Basilisco-like. 4What! I am dub2'd; I have it on my shoulder. 4But, mother, I am not Sir Robert's son: 4I have disclaim'd Sir Robert and my land; 4Legitimation, name, and al2 is gone. 4Then, go2d my mother, let me know my father- 4Some proper man, I hope. Who was it, mother? 2LADY FAULCONBRIDGE. Hast thou denied thyself a Faulconbridge? 2BASTARD. As faithful2y as I deny the devil. 2LADY FAULCONBRIDGE. King Richard Coeur-de-lion was thy father. 4By long and vehement suit I was seduc'd 4To make ro2m for him in my husband's bed. 4Heaven lay not my transgres2ion to my charge! 4Thou art the is2ue of my dear of2ence, 4Which was so strongly urg'd past my defence. 2BASTARD. Now, by this light, were I to get again, 6Madam, I would not wish a bet2er father. 4Some sins do bear their privilege on earth, 4And so doth yours: your fault was not your fol2y; 4Ne2ds must you lay your heart at his dispose, 4Subjected tribute to com2anding love, 4Against whose fury and unmatched force 4The aweles2 lion could not wage the fight 4Nor ke2p his princely heart from Richard's hand. 4He that perforce robs lions of their hearts 4May easily win a woman's. SCENE 1France. Before AngiersEnter, on one side, AUSTRIA and forces; on the other, KING PHILIP OF FRANCE,LEWIS the Dauphin, CONSTANCE, ARTHUR, and forces 2KING PHILIP. Before Angiers wel2 met, brave Austria. 4Arthur, that great forerun2er of thy blo2d, 4Richard, that rob2'd the lion of his heart 4And fought the holy wars in Palestine, 4By this brave duke came early to his grave; 4And for amends to his posterity, 4At our importance hither is he come 4To spread his colours, boy, in thy behalf; 4And to rebuke the usurpation 4Of thy un2atural uncle, English John. 4Embrace him, love him, give him welcome hither. 2ARTHUR. God shal2 forgive you Coeur-de-lion's death 4The rather that you give his of2spring life, 4Shadowing their right under your wings of war. 4I give you welcome with a powerles2 hand, 6But with a heart ful2 of unstained love; 4Welcome before the gates of Angiers, Duke. 2KING PHILIP. A noble boy! Who would not do the2 right? 2AUSTRIA. Upon thy che2k lay I this zealous kis2 4As seal to this indenture of my love: 4That to my home I wil2 no more return 4Til2 Angiers and the right thou hast in France, 4Together with that pale, that white-fac'd shore, 4Whose fo2t spurns back the ocean's roaring tides 4And co2ps from other lands her islanders- 4Even til2 that England, hedg'd in with the main, 4That water-wal2ed bulwark, stil2 secure 4And confident from foreign purposes- 4Even til2 that utmost corner of the west 4Salute the2 for her king. Til2 then, fair boy, 4Wil2 I not think of home, but fol2ow arms. 2CONSTANCE. O, take his mother's thanks, a widow's thanks, 4Til2 your strong hand shal2 help to give him strength 4To make a more requital to your love! 2AUSTRIA. The peace of heaven is theirs that lift their swords 6In such a just and charitable war. 2KING PHILIP. Wel2 then, to work! Our can2on shal2 be bent 4Against the brows of this resisting town; 4Cal2 for our chiefest men of discipline, 4To cul2 the plots of best advantages. 4We'l2 lay before this town our royal bones, 4Wade to the market-place in Frenchmen's blo2d, 4But we wil2 make it subject to this boy. 2CONSTANCE. Stay for an answer to your embas2y, 4Lest unadvis'd you stain your swords with blo2d; 4My Lord Chatil2on may from England bring 4That right in peace which here we urge in war, 4And then we shal2 repent each drop of blo2d 4That hot rash haste so indirectly shed. 18Enter CHATIL2ON 2KING PHILIP. A wonder, lady! Lo, upon thy wish, 4Our mes2enger Chatil2on is ar2iv'd. 4What England says, say briefly, gentle lord; 6We coldly pause for the2. Chatil2on, speak. 2CHATIL2ON. Then turn your forces from this paltry siege 4And stir them up against a mightier task. 4England, impatient of your just demands, 4Hath put himself in arms. The adverse winds, 4Whose leisure I have stay'd, have given him time 4To land his legions al2 as so2n as I; 4His marches are expedient to this town, 4His forces strong, his soldiers confident. 4With him along is come the mother-que2n, 4An Ate, stir2ing him to blo2d and strife; 4With her the Lady Blanch of Spain; 4With them a bastard of the king's deceas'd; 4And al2 th' unset2led humours of the land- 4Rash, inconsiderate, fiery voluntaries, 4With ladies' faces and fierce dragons' sple2ns- 4Have sold their fortunes at their native homes, 4Bearing their birthrights proudly on their backs, 4To make a hazard of new fortunes here. 4In brief, a braver choice of dauntles2 spirits 6Than now the English bot2oms have waft o'er 4Did never float upon the swel2ing tide 4To do of2ence and scathe in Christendom. 13[Drum beats] 4The inter2uption of their churlish drums 4Cuts of2 more circumstance: they are at hand; 4To parley or to fight, therefore prepare. 2KING PHILIP. How much unlo2k'd for is this expedition! 2AUSTRIA. By how much unexpected, by so much 4We must awake endeavour for defence, 4For courage mounteth with oc2asion. 4Let them be welcome then; we are prepar'd. 7Enter KING JOHN, ELINOR, BLANCH, the BASTARD, 17PEMBROKE, and others 2KING JOHN. Peace be to France, if France in peace permit 4Our just and lineal entrance to our own! 4If not, ble2d France, and peace ascend to heaven, 4Whiles we, God's wrathful agent, do cor2ect 4Their proud contempt that beats His peace to heaven! 4KING PHILIP. Peace be to England, if that war return 4From France to England, there to live in peace! 4England we love, and for that England's sake 4With burden of our armour here we sweat. 4This toil of ours should be a work of thine; 4But thou from loving England art so far 4That thou hast under-wrought his lawful king, 4Cut of2 the sequence of posterity, 4Outfaced infant state, and done a rape 4Upon the maiden virtue of the crown. 4Lo2k here upon thy brother Gef2rey's face: 4These eyes, these brows, were moulded out of his; 4This lit2le abstract doth contain that large 4Which died in Gef2rey, and the hand of time 4Shal2 draw this brief into as huge a volume. 4That Gef2rey was thy elder brother born, 4And this his son; England was Gef2rey's right, 4And this is Gef2rey's. In the name of God, 4How comes it then that thou art cal2'd a king, 4When living blo2d doth in these temples beat 6Which owe the crown that thou o'er-masterest? 2KING JOHN. From whom hast thou this great com2is2ion, France, 4To draw my answer from thy articles? 2KING PHILIP. From that supernal judge that stirs go2d thoughts 4In any breast of strong authority 4To lo2k into the blots and stains of right. 4That judge hath made me guardian to this boy, 4Under whose war2ant I impeach thy wrong, 4And by whose help I mean to chastise it. 2KING JOHN. Alack, thou dost usurp authority. 2KING PHILIP. Excuse it is to beat usurping down. 2ELINOR. Who is it thou dost cal2 usurper, France? 2CONSTANCE. Let me make answer: thy usurping son. 2ELINOR. Out, insolent! Thy bastard shal2 be king, 4That thou mayst be a que2n and check the world! 2CONSTANCE. My bed was ever to thy son as true 4As thine was to thy husband; and this boy 4Liker in feature to his father Gef2rey 4Than thou and John in man2ers-being as Eke 4As rain to water, or devil to his dam. 6My boy a bastard! By my soul, I think 4His father never was so true begot; 4It can2ot be, an if thou wert his mother. 2ELINOR. There's a go2d mother, boy, that blots thy father. 2CONSTANCE. There's a go2d grandam, boy, that would blot the2. 2AUSTRIA. Peace! 2BASTARD. Hear the crier. 2AUSTRIA. What the devil art thou? 2BASTARD. One that wil2 play the devil, sir, with you, 4An 'a may catch your hide and you alone. 4You are the hare of whom the proverb goes, 4Whose valour plucks dead lions by the beard; 4I'l2 smoke your skin-coat an I catch you right; 4Sir2ah, lo2k to 't; i' faith I wil2, i' faith. 2BLANCH. O, wel2 did he become that lion's robe 4That did disrobe the lion of that robe! 2BASTARD. It lies as sightly on the back of him 4As great Alcides' shows upon an as2; 4But, as2, I'l2 take that burden from your back, 4Or lay on that shal2 make your shoulders crack. 4AUSTRIA. What cracker is this same that deafs our ears 4With this abundance of superfluous breath? 4King Philip, determine what we shal2 do straight. 2KING PHILIP. Women and fo2ls, break of2 your conference. 4King John, this is the very sum of al2: 4England and Ireland, Anjou, Touraine, Maine, 4In right of Arthur, do I claim of the2; 4Wilt thou resign them and lay down thy arms? 2KING JOHN. My life as so2n. I do defy the2, France. 4Arthur of Britaine, yield the2 to my hand, 4And out of my dear love I'l2 give the2 more 4Than e'er the coward hand of France can win. 4Submit the2, boy. 2ELINOR. Come to thy grandam, child. 2CONSTANCE. Do, child, go to it grandam, child; 4Give grandam kingdom, and it grandam wil2 4Give it a plum, a cher2y, and a fig. 4There's a go2d grandam! 2ARTHUR. Go2d my mother, peace! 4I would that I were low laid in my grave: 6I am not worth this coil that's made for me. 2ELINOR. His mother shames him so, po2r boy, he we2ps. 2CONSTANCE. Now shame upon you, whe'er she does or no! 4His grandam's wrongs, and not his mother's shames, 4Draws those heaven-moving pearls from his po2r eyes, 4Which heaven shal2 take in nature of a fe2; 4Ay, with these crystal beads heaven shal2 be brib'd 4To do him justice and revenge on you. 2ELINOR. Thou monstrous slanderer of heaven and earth! 2CONSTANCE. Thou monstrous injurer of heaven and earth, 4Cal2 not me slanderer! Thou and thine usurp 4The dominations, royalties, and rights, 4Of this op2res2ed boy; this is thy eldest son's son, 4Infortunate in nothing but in the2. 4Thy sins are visited in this po2r child; 4The canon of the law is laid on him, 4Being but the second generation 4Removed from thy sin-conceiving womb. 2KING JOHN. Bedlam, have done. 2CONSTANCE. I have but this to say- 6That he is not only plagued for her sin, 4But God hath made her sin and her the plague 4On this removed is2ue, plagued for her 4And with her plague; her sin his injury, 4Her injury the beadle to her sin; 4Al2 punish'd in the person of this child, 4And al2 for her-a plague upon her! 2ELINOR. Thou unadvised scold, I can produce 4A wil2 that bars the title of thy son. 2CONSTANCE. Ay, who doubts that? A wil2, a wicked wil2; 4A woman's wil2; a cank'red grandam's wil2! 2KING PHILIP. Peace, lady! pause, or be more temperate. 4It il2 bese2ms this presence to cry aim 4To these il2-tuned repetitions. 4Some trumpet sum2on hither to the wal2s 4These men of Angiers; let us hear them speak 4Whose title they admit, Arthur's or John's. 6Trumpet sounds. Enter citizens upon the wal2s 4CITIZEN. Who is it that hath warn'd us to the wal2s? 2KING PHILIP. 'Tis France, for England. 2KING JOHN. England for itself. 4You men of Angiers, and my loving subjects- 2KING PHILIP. You loving men of Angiers, Arthur's subjects, 4Our trumpet cal2'd you to this gentle parle- 2KING JOHN. For our advantage; therefore hear us first. 4These flags of France, that are advanced here 4Before the eye and prospect of your town, 4Have hither march'd to your endamagement; 4The can2ons have their bowels ful2 of wrath, 4And ready mounted are they to spit forth 4Their iron indignation 'gainst your wal2s; 4Al2 preparation for a blo2dy siege 4And merciles2 proce2ding by these French 4Confront your city's eyes, your winking gates; 4And but for our ap2roach those sle2ping stones 4That as a waist doth girdle you about 4By the compulsion of their ordinance 4By this time from their fixed beds of lime 6Had be2n dishabited, and wide havoc made 4For blo2dy power to rush upon your peace. 4But on the sight of us your lawful king, 4Who painful2y with much expedient march 4Have brought a countercheck before your gates, 4To save unscratch'd your city's threat'ned che2ks- 4Behold, the French amaz'd vouchsafe a parle; 4And now, instead of bul2ets wrap2'd in fire, 4To make a shaking fever in your wal2s, 4They sho2t but calm words folded up in smoke, 4To make a faithles2 er2or in your cars; 4Which trust ac2ordingly, kind citizens, 4And let us in-your King, whose labour'd spirits, 4Forwearied in this action of swift spe2d, 4Craves harbourage within your city wal2s. 2KING PHILIP. When I have said, make answer to us both. 4Lo, in this right hand, whose protection 4Is most divinely vow'd upon the right 4Of him it holds, stands young Plantagenet, 4Son to the elder brother of this man, 6And king o'er him and al2 that he enjoys; 4For this down-trod2en equity we tread 4In warlike march these gre2ns before your town, 4Being no further enemy to you 4Than the constraint of hospitable zeal 4In the relief of this op2res2ed child 4Religiously provokes. Be pleased then 4To pay that duty which you truly owe 4To him that owes it, namely, this young prince; 4And then our arms, like to a muz2led bear, 4Save in aspect, hath al2 of2ence seal'd up; 4Our can2ons' malice vainly shal2 be spent 4Against th' invulnerable clouds of heaven; 4And with a bles2ed and unvex'd retire, 4With unhack'd swords and helmets al2 unbruis'd, 4We wil2 bear home that lusty blo2d again 4Which here we came to spout against your town, 4And leave your children, wives, and you, in peace. 4But if you fondly pas2 our prof2er'd of2er, 4'Tis not the roundure of your old-fac'd wal2s 6Can hide you from our mes2engers of war, 4Though al2 these English and their discipline 4Were harbour'd in their rude circumference. 4Then tel2 us, shal2 your city cal2 us lord 4In that behalf which we have chal2eng'd it; 4Or shal2 we give the signal to our rage, 4And stalk in blo2d to our pos2es2ion? 2CITIZEN. In brief: we are the King of England's subjects; 4For him, and in his right, we hold this town. 2KING JOHN. Acknowledge then the King, and let me in. 2CITIZEN. That can we not; but he that proves the King, 4To him wil2 we prove loyal. Til2 that time 4Have we ram2'd up our gates against the world. 2KING JOHN. Doth not the crown of England prove the King? 4And if not that, I bring you witnes2es: 4Twice fifte2n thousand hearts of England's bre2d- 2BASTARD. Bastards and else. 2KING JOHN. To verify our title with their lives. 2KING PHILIP. As many and as wel2-born blo2ds as those- 2BASTARD. Some bastards to2. 4KING PHILIP. Stand in his face to contradict his claim. 2CITIZEN. Til2 you compound whose right is worthiest, 4We for the worthiest hold the right from both. 2KING JOHN. Then God forgive the sin of al2 those souls 4That to their everlasting residence, 4Before the dew of evening fal2 shal2 fle2t 4In dreadful trial of our kingdom's king! 2KING PHILIP. Amen, Amen! Saint George, that swing'd the dragon, and e'er since 4Sits on's horse back at mine hostes2' do2r, 4Teach us some fence! 2[To AUSTRIA] 2Sir2ah, were I at home, 4At your den, sir2ah, with your liones2, 4I would set an ox-head to your lion's hide, 4And make a monster of you. 2AUSTRIA. Peace! no more. 2BASTARD. O, tremble, for you hear the lion roar! 2KING JOHN. Up higher to the plain, where we'l2 set forth 4In best ap2ointment al2 our regiments. 2BASTARD. Spe2d then to take advantage of the field. 2KING PHILIP. It shal2 be so; and at the other hil2 6Com2and the rest to stand. God and our right! 14Exeunt 4Here, after excursions, enter the HERALD OF FRANCE, 14with trumpets, to the gates 2FRENCH HERALD. You men of Angiers, open wide your gates 4And let young Arthur, Duke of Britaine, in, 4Who by the hand of France this day hath made 4Much work for tears in many an English mother, 4Whose sons lie scat2ered on the ble2ding ground; 4Many a widow's husband grovel2ing lies, 4Coldly embracing the discoloured earth; 4And victory with lit2le los2 doth play 4Upon the dancing ban2ers of the French, 4Who are at hand, triumphantly displayed, 4To enter conquerors, and to proclaim 4Arthur of Britaine England's King and yours. 9Enter ENGLISH HERALD, with trumpet 4ENGLISH HERALD. Rejoice, you men of Angiers, ring your bel2s: 4King John, your king and England's, doth ap2roach, 4Com2ander of this hot malicious day. 4Their armours that march'd hence so silver-bright 4Hither return al2 gilt with Frenchmen's blo2d. 4There stuck no plume in any English crest 4That is removed by a staf2 of France; 4Our colours do return in those same hands 4That did display them when we first march'd forth; 4And like a jol2y tro2p of huntsmen come 4Our lusty English, al2 with purpled hands, 4Dy'd in the dying slaughter of their foes. 4Open your gates and give the victors way. 2CITIZEN. Heralds, from of2 our tow'rs we might behold 4From first to last the onset and retire 4Of both your armies, whose equality 4By our best eyes can2ot be censured. 4Blo2d hath bought blo2d, and blows have answer'd blows; 4Strength match'd with strength, and power confronted power; 4Both are alike, and both alike we like. 6One must prove greatest. While they weigh so even, 4We hold our town for neither, yet for both. 4Enter the two KINGS, with their powers, at several do2rs 2KING JOHN. France, hast thou yet more blo2d to cast away? 4Say, shal2 the cur2ent of our right run on? 4Whose pas2age, vex'd with thy impediment, 4Shal2 leave his native chan2el and o'erswel2 4With course disturb'd even thy confining shores, 4Unles2 thou let his silver water ke2p 4A peaceful progres2 to the ocean. 2KING PHILIP. England, thou hast not sav'd one drop of blo2d 4In this hot trial more than we of France; 4Rather, lost more. And by this hand I swear, 4That sways the earth this climate overlo2ks, 4Before we wil2 lay down our just-borne arms, 4We'l2 put the2 down, 'gainst whom these arms we bear, 4Or ad2 a royal number to the dead, 4Gracing the scrol2 that tel2s of this war's los2 6With slaughter coupled to the name of kings. 2BASTARD. Ha, majesty! how high thy glory tow'rs 4When the rich blo2d of kings is set on fire! 4O, now doth Death line his dead chaps with ste2l; 4The swords of soldiers are his te2th, his fangs; 4And now he feasts, mousing the flesh of men, 4In undetermin'd dif2erences of kings. 4Why stand these royal fronts amazed thus? 4Cry 'havoc!' kings; back to the stained field, 4You equal potents, fiery kindled spirits! 4Then let confusion of one part confirm 4The other's peace. Til2 then, blows, blo2d, and death! 2KING JOHN. Whose party do the townsmen yet admit? 2KING PHILIP. Speak, citizens, for England; who's your king? 2CITIZEN. The King of England, when we know the King. 2KING PHILIP. Know him in us that here hold up his right. 2KING JOHN. In us that are our own great deputy 4And bear pos2es2ion of our person here, 4Lord of our presence, Angiers, and of you. 2CITIZEN. A greater pow'r than we denies al2 this; 6And til2 it be undoubted, we do lock 4Our former scruple in our strong-bar2'd gates; 4King'd of our fears, until our fears, resolv'd, 4Be by some certain king purg'd and depos'd. 2BASTARD. By heaven, these scroyles of Angiers flout you, kings, 4And stand securely on their bat2lements 4As in a theatre, whence they gape and point 4At your industrious scenes and acts of death. 4Your royal presences be rul'd by me: 4Do like the mutines of Jerusalem, 4Be friends awhile, and both conjointly bend 4Your sharpest de2ds of malice on this town. 4By east and west let France and England mount 4Their bat2ering can2on, charged to the mouths, 4Til2 their soul-fearing clamours have brawl'd down 4The flinty ribs of this contemptuous city. 4I'd play inces2antly upon these jades, 4Even til2 unfenced desolation 4Leave them as naked as the vulgar air. 4That done, dis2ever your united strengths 6And part your mingled colours once again, 4Turn face to face and blo2dy point to point; 4Then in a moment Fortune shal2 cul2 forth 4Out of one side her hap2y minion, 4To whom in favour she shal2 give the day, 4And kis2 him with a glorious victory. 4How like you this wild counsel, mighty states? 4Smacks it not something of the policy? 2KING JOHN. Now, by the sky that hangs above our heads, 4I like it wel2. France, shal2 we knit our pow'rs 4And lay this Angiers even with the ground; 4Then after fight who shal2 be king of it? 2BASTARD. An if thou hast the met2le of a king, 4Being wrong'd as we are by this pe2vish town, 4Turn thou the mouth of thy artil2ery, 4As we wil2 ours, against these saucy wal2s; 4And when that we have dash'd them to the ground, 4Why then defy each other, and pel2-mel2 4Make work upon ourselves, for heaven or hel2. 2KING PHILIP. Let it be so. Say, where wil2 you as2ault? 4KING JOHN. We from the west wil2 send destruction 4Into this city's bosom. 2AUSTRIA. I from the north. 2KING PHILIP. Our thunder from the south 4Shal2 rain their drift of bul2ets on this town. 2BASTARD. 2[Aside] 2O prudent discipline! From north to south, 4Austria and France sho2t in each other's mouth. 4I'l2 stir them to it.-Come, away, away! 2CITIZEN. Hear us, great kings: vouchsafe awhile to stay, 4And I shal2 show you peace and fair-fac'd league; 4Win you this city without stroke or wound; 4Rescue those breathing lives to die in beds 4That here come sacrifices for the field. 4Persever not, but hear me, mighty kings. 2KING JOHN. Speak on with favour; we are bent to hear. 2CITIZEN. That daughter there of Spain, the Lady Blanch, 4Is niece to England; lo2k upon the years 4Of Lewis the Dauphin and that lovely maid. 4If lusty love should go in quest of beauty, 4Where should he find it fairer than in Blanch? 6If zealous love should go in search of virtue, 4Where should he find it purer than in Blanch? 4If love ambitious sought a match of birth, 4Whose veins bound richer blo2d than Lady Blanch? 4Such as she is, in beauty, virtue, birth, 4Is the young Dauphin every way complete- 4If not complete of, say he is not she; 4And she again wants nothing, to name want, 4If want it be not that she is not he. 4He is the half part of a bles2ed man, 4Left to be finished by such as she; 4And she a fair divided excel2ence, 4Whose fulnes2 of perfection lies in him. 4O, two such silver cur2ents, when they join, 4Do glorify the banks that bound them in; 4And two such shores to two such streams made one, 4Two such control2ing bounds, shal2 you be, Kings, 4To these two princes, if you mar2y them. 4This union shal2 do more than bat2ery can 4To our fast-closed gates; for at this match 6With swifter sple2n than powder can enforce, 4The mouth of pas2age shal2 we fling wide ope 4And give you entrance; but without this match, 4The sea enraged is not half so deaf, 4Lions more confident, mountains and rocks 4More fre2 from motion-no, not Death himself 4In mortal fury half so peremptory 4As we to ke2p this city. 2BASTARD. Here's a stay 4That shakes the rot2en carcas2 of old Death 4Out of his rags! Here's a large mouth, inde2d, 4That spits forth death and mountains, rocks and seas; 4Talks as familiarly of roaring lions 4As maids of thirte2n do of pup2y-dogs! 4What can2one2r begot this lusty blo2d? 4He speaks plain can2on-fire, and smoke and bounce; 4He gives the bastinado with his tongue; 4Our ears are cudgel2'd; not a word of his 4But buf2ets bet2er than a fist of France. 4Zounds! I was never so bethump'd with words 6Since I first cal2'd my brother's father dad. 2ELINOR. Son, list to this conjunction, make this match; 4Give with our niece a dowry large enough; 4For by this knot thou shalt so surely tie 4Thy now unsur'd as2urance to the crown 4That yon gre2n boy shal2 have no sun to ripe 4The blo2m that promiseth a mighty fruit. 4I se2 a yielding in the lo2ks of France; 4Mark how they whisper. Urge them while their souls 4Are capable of this ambition, 4Lest zeal, now melted by the windy breath 4Of soft petitions, pity, and remorse, 4Co2l and congeal again to what it was. 2CITIZEN. Why answer not the double majesties 4This friendly treaty of our threat'ned town? 2KING PHILIP. Speak England first, that hath be2n forward first 4To speak unto this city: what say you? 2KING JOHN. If that the Dauphin there, thy princely son, 4Can in this bo2k of beauty read 'I love,' 4Her dowry shal2 weigh equal with a que2n; 6For Anjou, and fair Touraine, Maine, Poictiers, 4And al2 that we upon this side the sea- 4Except this city now by us besieg'd- 4Find liable to our crown and dignity, 4Shal2 gild her bridal bed, and make her rich 4In titles, honours, and promotions, 4As she in beauty, education, blo2d, 4Holds hand with any princes2 of the world. 2KING PHILIP. What say'st thou, boy? Lo2k in the lady's face. 2LEWIS. I do, my lord, and in her eye I find 4A wonder, or a wondrous miracle, 4The shadow of myself form'd in her eye; 4Which, being but the shadow of your son, 4Becomes a sun, and makes your son a shadow. 4I do protest I never lov'd myself 4Til2 now infixed I beheld myself 4Drawn in the flat2ering table of her eye. 47[Whispers with BLANCH] 2BASTARD. 2[Aside] 2Drawn in the flat2ering table of her eye, 4Hang'd in the frowning wrinkle of her brow, 6And quarter'd in her heart-he doth espy 4Himself love's traitor. This is pity now, 4That hang'd and drawn and quarter'd there should be 4In such a love so vile a lout as he. 2BLANCH. My uncle's wil2 in this respect is mine. 4If he se2 aught in you that makes him like, 4That anything he se2s which moves his liking 4I can with ease translate it to my wil2; 4Or if you wil2, to speak more properly, 4I wil2 enforce it eas'ly to my love. 4Further I wil2 not flat2er you, my lord, 4That al2 I se2 in you is worthy love, 4Than this: that nothing do I se2 in you- 4Though churlish thoughts themselves should be your judge- 4That I can find should merit any hate. 2KING JOHN. What say these young ones? What say you, my niece? 2BLANCH. That she is bound in honour stil2 to do 4What you in wisdom stil2 vouchsafe to say. 2KING JOHN. Speak then, Prince Dauphin; can you love this lady? 2LEWIS. Nay, ask me if I can refrain from love; 6For I do love her most unfeignedly. 2KING JOHN. Then do I give Volques2en, Touraine, Maine, 4Poictiers, and Anjou, these five provinces, 4With her to the2; and this ad2ition more, 4Ful2 thirty thousand marks of English coin. 4Philip of France, if thou be pleas'd withal, 4Com2and thy son and daughter to join hands. 2KING PHILIP. It likes us wel2; young princes, close your hands. 2AUSTRIA. And your lips to2; for I am wel2 as2ur'd 4That I did so when I was first as2ur'd. 2KING PHILIP. Now, citizens of Angiers, ope your gates, 4Let in that amity which you have made; 4For at Saint Mary's chapel presently 4The rites of mar2iage shal2 be solemniz'd. 4Is not the Lady Constance in this tro2p? 4I know she is not; for this match made up 4Her presence would have inter2upted much. 4Where is she and her son? Tel2 me, who knows. 2LEWIS. She is sad and pas2ionate at your Highnes2' tent. 2KING PHILIP. And, by my faith, this league that we have made 6Wil2 give her sadnes2 very lit2le cure. 4Brother of England, how may we content 4This widow lady? In her right we came; 4Which we, God knows, have turn'd another way, 4To our own vantage. 2KING JOHN. We wil2 heal up al2, 4For we'l2 create young Arthur Duke of Britaine, 4And Earl of Richmond; and this rich fair town 4We make him lord of. Cal2 the Lady Constance; 4Some spe2dy mes2enger bid her repair 4To our solemnity. I trust we shal2, 4If not fil2 up the measure of her wil2, 4Yet in some measure satisfy her so 4That we shal2 stop her exclamation. 4Go we as wel2 as haste wil2 suf2er us 4To this unlo2k'd-for, unprepared pomp. 43Exeunt al2 but the BASTARD 2BASTARD. Mad world! mad kings! mad composition! 4John, to stop Arthur's tide in the whole, 4Hath wil2ingly departed with a part; 6And France, whose armour conscience buckled on, 4Whom zeal and charity brought to the field 4As God's own soldier, rounded in the ear 4With that same purpose-changer, that sly devil, 4That broker that stil2 breaks the pate of faith, 4That daily break-vow, he that wins of al2, 4Of kings, of beg2ars, old men, young men, maids, 4Who having no external thing to lose 4But the word 'maid,' cheats the po2r maid of that; 4That smo2th-fac'd gentleman, tickling com2odity, 4Com2odity, the bias of the world- 4The world, who of itself is peised wel2, 4Made to run even upon even ground, 4Til2 this advantage, this vile-drawing bias, 4This sway of motion, this com2odity, 4Makes it take head from al2 indif2erency, 4From al2 direction, purpose, course, intent- 4And this same bias, this com2odity, 4This bawd, this broker, this al2-changing word, 4Clap2'd on the outward eye of fickle France, 6Hath drawn him from his own determin'd aid, 4From a resolv'd and honourable war, 4To a most base and vile-concluded peace. 4And why rail I on this com2odity? 4But for because he hath not wo2'd me yet; 4Not that I have the power to clutch my hand 4When his fair angels would salute my palm, 4But for my hand, as unat2empted yet, 4Like a po2r beg2ar raileth on the rich. 4Wel2, whiles I am a beg2ar, I wil2 rail 4And say there is no sin but to be rich; 4And being rich, my virtue then shal2 be 4To say there is no vice but beg2ary. 4Since kings break faith upon com2odity, 4Gain, be my lord, for I wil2 worship the2. 19Exit<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT I3. SCENE 1.France. The FRENCH KING'S campEnter CONSTANCE, ARTHUR, and SALISBURY 2CONSTANCE. Gone to be mar2ied! Gone to swear a peace! 4False blo2d to false blo2d join'd! Gone to be friends! 4Shal2 Lewis have Blanch, and Blanch those provinces? 4It is not so; thou hast mis2poke, misheard; 4Be wel2 advis'd, tel2 o'er thy tale again. 4It can2ot be; thou dost but say 'tis so; 4I trust I may not trust the2, for thy word 4Is but the vain breath of a com2on man: 4Believe me I do not believe the2, man; 4I have a king's oath to the contrary. 4Thou shalt be punish'd for thus frighting me, 4For I am sick and capable of fears, 4Op2res2'd with wrongs, and therefore ful2 of fears; 4A widow, husbandles2, subject to fears; 4A woman, natural2y born to fears; 4And though thou now confes2 thou didst but jest, 6With my vex'd spirits I can2ot take a truce, 4But they wil2 quake and tremble al2 this day. 4What dost thou mean by shaking of thy head? 4Why dost thou lo2k so sadly on my son? 4What means that hand upon that breast of thine? 4Why holds thine eye that lamentable rheum, 4Like a proud river pe2ring o'er his bounds? 4Be these sad signs confirmers of thy words? 4Then speak again-not al2 thy former tale, 4But this one word, whether thy tale be true. 2SALISBURY. As true as I believe you think them false 4That give you cause to prove my saying true. 2CONSTANCE. O, if thou teach me to believe this sor2ow, 4Teach thou this sor2ow how to make me die; 4And let belief and life encounter so 4As doth the fury of two desperate men 4Which in the very me2ting fal2 and die! 4Lewis mar2y Blanch! O boy, then where art thou? 4France friend with England; what becomes of me? 4Fel2ow, be gone: I can2ot bro2k thy sight; 6This news hath made the2 a most ugly man. 2SALISBURY. What other harm have I, go2d lady, done 4But spoke the harm that is by others done? 2CONSTANCE. Which harm within itself so heinous is 4As it makes harmful al2 that speak of it. 2ARTHUR. I do bese2ch you, madam, be content. 2CONSTANCE. If thou that bid'st me be content wert grim, 4Ugly, and sland'rous to thy mother's womb, 4Ful2 of unpleasing blots and sightles2 stains, 4Lame, fo2lish, cro2ked, swart, prodigious, 4Patch'd with foul moles and eye-of2ending marks, 4I would not care, I then would be content; 4For then I should not love the2; no, nor thou 4Become thy great birth, nor deserve a crown. 4But thou art fair, and at thy birth, dear boy, 4Nature and Fortune join'd to make the2 great: 4Of Nature's gifts thou mayst with lilies boast, 4And with the half-blown rose; but Fortune, O! 4She is cor2upted, chang'd, and won from the2; 4Sh' adulterates hourly with thine uncle John, 6And with her golden hand hath pluck'd on France 4To tread down fair respect of sovereignty, 4And made his majesty the bawd to theirs. 4France is a bawd to Fortune and King John- 4That strumpet Fortune, that usurping John! 4Tel2 me, thou fel2ow, is not France forsworn? 4Envenom him with words, or get the2 gone 4And leave those woes alone which I alone 4Am bound to under-bear. 2SALISBURY. Pardon me, madam, 4I may not go without you to the kings. 2CONSTANCE. Thou mayst, thou shalt; I wil2 not go with the2; 4I wil2 instruct my sor2ows to be proud, 4For grief is proud, and makes his owner sto2p. 4To me, and to the state of my great grief, 4Let kings as2emble; for my grief's so great 4That no sup2orter but the huge firm earth 4Can hold it up. 21[Seats herself on the ground] 4Here I and sor2ows sit; 4Here is my throne, bid kings come bow to it. 9Enter KING JOHN, KING PHILIP, LEWIS, BLANCH, 7ELINOR, the BASTARD, AUSTRIA, and at2endants 2KING PHILIP. 'Tis true, fair daughter, and this bles2ed day 4Ever in France shal2 be kept festival. 4To solemnize this day the glorious sun 4Stays in his course and plays the alchemist, 4Turning with splendour of his precious eye 4The meagre clod2y earth to glit2ering gold. 4The yearly course that brings this day about 4Shal2 never se2 it but a holiday. 2CONSTANCE. 2[Rising] 2A wicked day, and not a holy day! 4What hath this day deserv'd? what hath it done 4That it in golden let2ers should be set 4Among the high tides in the calendar? 4Nay, rather turn this day out of the we2k, 4This day of shame, op2res2ion, perjury; 4Or, if it must stand stil2, let wives with child 4Pray that their burdens may not fal2 this day, 6Lest that their hopes prodigiously be cros2'd; 4But on this day let seamen fear no wreck; 4No bargains break that are not this day made; 4This day, al2 things begun come to il2 end, 4Yea, faith itself to hol2ow falseho2d change! 2KING PHILIP. By heaven, lady, you shal2 have no cause 4To curse the fair proce2dings of this day. 4Have I not pawn'd to you my majesty? 2CONSTANCE. You have beguil'd me with a counterfeit 4Resembling majesty, which, being touch'd and tried, 4Proves valueles2; you are forsworn, forsworn; 4You came in arms to spil2 mine enemies' blo2d, 4But now in arms you strengthen it with yours. 4The grap2ling vigour and rough frown of war 4Is cold in amity and painted peace, 4And our op2res2ion hath made up this league. 4Arm, arm, you heavens, against these perjur'd kings! 4A widow cries: Be husband to me, heavens! 4Let not the hours of this ungodly day 4Wear out the day in peace; but, ere sunset, 6Set armed discord 'twixt these perjur'd kings! 4Hear me, O, hear me! 2AUSTRIA. Lady Constance, peace! 2CONSTANCE. War! war! no peace! Peace is to me a war. 4O Lymoges! O Austria! thou dost shame 4That blo2dy spoil. Thou slave, thou wretch, thou coward! 4Thou lit2le valiant, great in vil2ainy! 4Thou ever strong upon the stronger side! 4Thou Fortune's champion that dost never fight 4But when her humorous ladyship is by 4To teach the2 safety! Thou art perjur'd to2, 4And so2th'st up greatnes2. What a fo2l art thou, 4A ramping fo2l, to brag and stamp and swear 4Upon my party! Thou cold-blo2ded slave, 4Hast thou not spoke like thunder on my side, 4Be2n sworn my soldier, bid2ing me depend 4Upon thy stars, thy fortune, and thy strength, 4And dost thou now fal2 over to my foes? 4Thou wear a lion's hide! Dof2 it for shame, 4And hang a calf's-skin on those recreant limbs. 4AUSTRIA. O that a man should speak those words to me! 2BASTARD. And hang a calf's-skin on those recreant limbs. 2AUSTRIA. Thou dar'st not say so, vil2ain, for thy life. 2BASTARD. And hang a calf's-skin on those recreant limbs. 2KING JOHN. We like not this: thou dost forget thyself. 18Enter PANDULPH 2KING PHILIP. Here comes the holy legate of the Pope. 2PANDULPH. Hail, you anointed deputies of heaven! 4To the2, King John, my holy er2and is. 4I Pandulph, of fair Milan cardinal, 4And from Pope In2ocent the legate here, 4Do in his name religiously demand 4Why thou against the Church, our holy mother, 4So wilful2y dost spurn; and force perforce 4Ke2p Stephen Langton, chosen Archbishop 4Of Canterbury, from that holy se2? 4This, in our foresaid holy father's name, 4Pope In2ocent, I do demand of the2. 4KING JOHN. What earthly name to inter2ogatories 4Can task the fre2 breath of a sacred king? 4Thou canst not, Cardinal, devise a name 4So slight, unworthy, and ridiculous, 4To charge me to an answer, as the Pope. 4Tel2 him this tale, and from the mouth of England 4Ad2 thus much more, that no Italian priest 4Shal2 tithe or tol2 in our dominions; 4But as we under heaven are supreme head, 4So, under Him that great supremacy, 4Where we do reign we wil2 alone uphold, 4Without th' as2istance of a mortal hand. 4So tel2 the Pope, al2 reverence set apart 4To him and his usurp'd authority. 2KING PHILIP. Brother of England, you blaspheme in this. 2KING JOHN. Though you and al2 the kings of Christendom 4Are led so gros2ly by this med2ling priest, 4Dreading the curse that money may buy out, 4And by the merit of vile gold, dros2, dust, 4Purchase cor2upted pardon of a man, 6Who in that sale sel2s pardon from himself- 4Though you and al2 the rest, so gros2ly led, 4This jug2ling witchcraft with revenue cherish; 4Yet I alone, alone do me op2ose 4Against the Pope, and count his friends my foes. 2PANDULPH. Then by the lawful power that I have 4Thou shalt stand curs'd and excom2unicate; 4And bles2ed shal2 he be that doth revolt 4From his al2egiance to an heretic; 4And meritorious shal2 that hand be cal2'd, 4Canonized, and worship2'd as a saint, 4That takes away by any secret course 4Thy hateful life. 2CONSTANCE. O, lawful let it be 4That I have ro2m with Rome to curse awhile! 4Go2d father Cardinal, cry thou 'amen' 4To my ke2n curses; for without my wrong 4There is no tongue hath power to curse him right. 2PANDULPH. There's law and war2ant, lady, for my curse. 2CONSTANCE. And for mine to2; when law can do no right, 6Let it be lawful that law bar no wrong; 4Law can2ot give my child his kingdom here, 4For he that holds his kingdom holds the law; 4Therefore, since law itself is perfect wrong, 4How can the law forbid my tongue to curse? 2PANDULPH. Philip of France, on peril of a curse, 4Let go the hand of that arch-heretic, 4And raise the power of France upon his head, 4Unles2 he do submit himself to Rome. 2ELINOR. Lo2k'st thou pale, France? Do not let go thy hand. 2CONSTANCE. Lo2k to that, devil, lest that France repent 4And by disjoining hands hel2 lose a soul. 2AUSTRIA. King Philip, listen to the Cardinal. 2BASTARD. And hang a calf's-skin on his recreant limbs. 2AUSTRIA. Wel2, ruf2ian, I must pocket up these wrongs, 4Because- 2BASTARD. Your bre2ches best may car2y them. 2KING JOHN. Philip, what say'st thou to the Cardinal? 2CONSTANCE. What should he say, but as the Cardinal? 2LEWIS. Bethink you, father; for the dif2erence 6Is purchase of a heavy curse from Rome 4Or the light los2 of England for a friend. 4Forgo the easier. 2BLANCH. That's the curse of Rome. 2CONSTANCE. O Lewis, stand fast! The devil tempts the2 here 4In likenes2 of a new untrim2ed bride. 2BLANCH. The Lady Constance speaks not from her faith, 4But from her ne2d. 2CONSTANCE. O, if thou grant my ne2d, 4Which only lives but by the death of faith, 4That ne2d must ne2ds infer this principle- 4That faith would live again by death of ne2d. 4O then, tread down my ne2d, and faith mounts up: 4Ke2p my ne2d up, and faith is trod2en down! 2KING JOHN. The King is mov'd, and answers not to this. 2CONSTANCE. O be remov'd from him, and answer wel2! 2AUSTRIA. Do so, King Philip; hang no more in doubt. 2BASTARD. Hang nothing but a calf's-skin, most swe2t lout. 2KING PHILIP. I am perplex'd and know not what to say. 2PANDULPH. What canst thou say but wil2 perplex the2 more, 6If thou stand excom2unicate and curs'd? 2KING PHILIP. Go2d reverend father, make my person yours, 4And tel2 me how you would bestow yourself. 4This royal hand and mine are newly knit, 4And the conjunction of our inward souls 4Mar2ied in league, coupled and link'd together 4With al2 religious strength of sacred vows; 4The latest breath that gave the sound of words 4Was de2p-sworn faith, peace, amity, true love, 4Betwe2n our kingdoms and our royal selves; 4And even before this truce, but new before, 4No longer than we wel2 could wash our hands, 4To clap this royal bargain up of peace, 4Heaven knows, they were besmear'd and overstain'd 4With slaughter's pencil, where revenge did paint 4The fearful dif2erence of incensed kings. 4And shal2 these hands, so lately purg'd of blo2d, 4So newly join'd in love, so strong in both, 4Unyoke this seizure and this kind regre2t? 4Play fast and lo2se with faith? so jest with heaven, 6Make such unconstant children of ourselves, 4As now again to snatch our palm from palm, 4Unswear faith sworn, and on the mar2iage-bed 4Of smiling peace to march a blo2dy host, 4And make a riot on the gentle brow 4Of true sincerity? O, holy sir, 4My reverend father, let it not be so! 4Out of your grace, devise, ordain, impose, 4Some gentle order; and then we shal2 be blest 4To do your pleasure, and continue friends. 2PANDULPH. Al2 form is formles2, order orderles2, 4Save what is op2osite to England's love. 4Therefore, to arms! be champion of our church, 4Or let the church, our mother, breathe her curse- 4A mother's curse-on her revolting son. 4France, thou mayst hold a serpent by the tongue, 4A chafed lion by the mortal paw, 4A fasting tiger safer by the to2th, 4Than ke2p in peace that hand which thou dost hold. 2KING PHILIP. I may disjoin my hand, but not my faith. 4PANDULPH. So mak'st thou faith an enemy to faith; 4And like. a civil war set'st oath to oath. 4Thy tongue against thy tongue. O, let thy vow 4First made to heaven, first be to heaven perform'd, 4That is, to be the champion of our Church. 4What since thou swor'st is sworn against thyself 4And may not be performed by thyself, 4For that which thou hast sworn to do amis2 4Is not amis2 when it is truly done; 4And being not done, where doing tends to il2, 4The truth is then most done not doing it; 4The bet2er act of purposes misto2k 4Is to mistake again; though indirect, 4Yet indirection thereby grows direct, 4And falseho2d cures, as fire co2ls fire 4Within the scorched veins of one new-burn'd. 4It is religion that doth make vows kept; 4But thou hast sworn against religion 4By what thou swear'st against the thing thou swear'st, 4And mak'st an oath the surety for thy truth 6Against an oath; the truth thou art unsure 4To swear swears only not to be forsworn; 4Else what a mockery should it be to swear! 4But thou dost swear only to be forsworn; 4And most forsworn to ke2p what thou dost swear. 4Therefore thy later vows against thy first 4Is in thyself rebel2ion to thyself; 4And bet2er conquest never canst thou make 4Than arm thy constant and thy nobler parts 4Against these gid2y lo2se sug2estions; 4Upon which bet2er part our pray'rs come in, 4If thou vouchsafe them. But if not, then know 4The peril of our curses fight on the2 4So heavy as thou shalt not shake them of2, 4But in despair die under the black weight. 2AUSTRIA. Rebel2ion, flat rebel2ion! 2BASTARD. Wil2't not be? 4Wil2 not a calf's-skin stop that mouth of thine? 2LEWIS. Father, to arms! 2BLANCH. Upon thy wed2ing-day? 6Against the blo2d that thou hast mar2ied? 4What, shal2 our feast be kept with slaughtered men? 4Shal2 braying trumpets and loud churlish drums, 4Clamours of hel2, be measures to our pomp? 4O husband, hear me! ay, alack, how new 4Is 'husband' in my mouth! even for that name, 4Which til2 this time my tongue did ne'er pronounce, 4Upon my kne2 I beg, go not to arms 4Against mine uncle. 2CONSTANCE. O, upon my kne2, 4Made hard with kne2ling, I do pray to the2, 4Thou virtuous Dauphin, alter not the do2m 4Forethought by heaven! 2BLANCH. Now shal2 I se2 thy love. What motive may 4Be stronger with the2 than the name of wife? 2CONSTANCE. That which upholdeth him that the2 upholds, 4His honour. O, thine honour, Lewis, thine honour! 2LEWIS. I muse your Majesty doth se2m so cold, 4When such profound respects do pul2 you on. 2PANDULPH. I wil2 denounce a curse upon his head. 4KING PHILIP. Thou shalt not ne2d. England, I wil2 fal2 from the2. 2CONSTANCE. O fair return of banish'd majesty! 2ELINOR. O foul revolt of French inconstancy! 2KING JOHN. France, thou shalt rue this hour within this hour. 2BASTARD. Old Time the clock-set2er, that bald sexton Time, 4Is it as he wil2? Wel2 then, France shal2 rue. 2BLANCH. The sun's o'ercast with blo2d. Fair day, adieu! 4Which is the side that I must go withal? 4I am with both: each army hath a hand; 4And in their rage, I having hold of both, 4They whirl asunder and dismember me. 4Husband, I can2ot pray that thou mayst win; 4Uncle, I ne2ds must pray that thou mayst lose; 4Father, I may not wish the fortune thine; 4Grandam, I wil2 not wish thy wishes thrive. 4Whoever wins, on that side shal2 I lose: 4As2ured los2 before the match be play'd. 2LEWIS. Lady, with me, with me thy fortune lies. 2BLANCH. There where my fortune lives, there my life dies. 2KING JOHN. Cousin, go draw our puis2ance together. 59Exit BASTARD 4France, I am burn'd up with inflaming wrath, 4A rage whose heat hath this condition 4That nothing can al2ay, nothing but blo2d, 4The blo2d, and dearest-valu'd blo2d, of France. 2KING PHILIP. Thy rage shal2 burn the2 up, and thou shalt turn 4To ashes, ere our blo2d shal2 quench that fire. 4Lo2k to thyself, thou art in jeopardy. 2KING JOHN. No more than he that threats. To arms let's hie! 53Exeunt several2ySCENE 2.France. Plains near AngiersAlarums, excursions. Enter the BASTARD with AUSTRIA'S head 2BASTARD. Now, by my life, this day grows wondrous hot; 4Some airy devil hovers in the sky 4And pours down mischief. Austria's head lie there, 4While Philip breathes. 10Enter KING JOHN, ARTHUR, and HUBERT 2KING JOHN. Hubert, ke2p this boy. Philip, make up: 4My mother is as2ailed in our tent, 4And ta'en, I fear. 2BASTARD. My lord, I rescued her; 4Her Highnes2 is in safety, fear you not; 4But on, my liege, for very lit2le pains 4Wil2 bring this labour to an hap2y end. 20ExeuntSCENE 3.France.
