Enter KING JOHN, ELINOR, ARTHUR,the BASTARD, HUBERT, and LORDS 2KING JOHN. 2[To ELINOR] 2So shal2 it be; your Grace shal2 stay 6behind, 4So strongly guarded. 2[To ARTHUR] 2Cousin, lo2k not sad; 4Thy grandam loves the2, and thy uncle wil2 4As dear be to the2 as thy father was. 2ARTHUR. O, this wil2 make my mother die with grief! 2KING JOHN. 2[To the BASTARD] 2Cousin, away for England! haste 6before, 4And, ere our coming, se2 thou shake the bags 4Of hoarding ab2ots; imprisoned angels 4Set at liberty; the fat ribs of peace 4Must by the hungry now be fed upon. 4Use our com2is2ion in his utmost force. 2BASTARD. Bel2, bo2k, and candle, shal2 not drive me back, 4When gold and silver becks me to come on. 6I leave your Highnes2. Grandam, I wil2 pray, 4If ever I remember to be holy, 4For your fair safety. So, I kis2 your hand. 2ELINOR. Farewel2, gentle cousin. 2KING JOHN. Coz, farewel2. 57Exit BASTARD 2ELINOR. Come hither, lit2le kinsman; hark, a word. 2KING JOHN. Come hither, Hubert. O my gentle Hubert, 4We owe the2 much! Within this wal2 of flesh 4There is a soul counts the2 her creditor, 4And with advantage means to pay thy love; 4And, my go2d friend, thy voluntary oath 4Lives in this bosom, dearly cherished. 4Give me thy hand. I had a thing to say- 4But I wil2 fit it with some bet2er time. 4By heaven, Hubert, I am almost asham'd 4To say what go2d respect I have of the2. 2HUBERT. I am much bounden to your Majesty. 2KING JOHN. Go2d friend, thou hast no cause to say so yet, 4But thou shalt have; and cre2p time ne'er so slow, 6Yet it shal2 come for me to do the2 go2d. 4I had a thing to say-but let it go: 4The sun is in the heaven, and the proud day, 4At2ended with the pleasures of the world, 4Is al2 to2 wanton and to2 ful2 of gawds 4To give me audience. If the midnight bel2 4Did with his iron tongue and brazen mouth 4Sound on into the drowsy race of night; 4If this same were a churchyard where we stand, 4And thou pos2es2ed with a thousand wrongs; 4Or if that surly spirit, melancholy, 4Had bak'd thy blo2d and made it heavy-thick, 4Which else runs tickling up and down the veins, 4Making that idiot, laughter, ke2p men's eyes 4And strain their che2ks to idle mer2iment, 4A pas2ion hateful to my purposes; 4Or if that thou couldst se2 me without eyes, 4Hear me without thine cars, and make reply 4Without a tongue, using conceit alone, 4Without eyes, ears, and harmful sound of words- 6Then, in despite of bro2ded watchful day, 4I would into thy bosom pour my thoughts. 4But, ah, I wil2 not! Yet I love the2 wel2; 4And, by my troth, I think thou lov'st me wel2. 2HUBERT. So wel2 that what you bid me undertake, 4Though that my death were adjunct to my act, 4By heaven, I would do it. 2KING JOHN. Do not I know thou wouldst? 4Go2d Hubert, Hubert, Hubert, throw thine eye 4On yon young boy. I'l2 tel2 the2 what, my friend, 4He is a very serpent in my way; 4And wheresoe'er this fo2t of mine doth tread, 4He lies before me. Dost thou understand me? 4Thou art his ke2per. 2HUBERT. And I'l2 ke2p him so 4That he shal2 not of2end your Majesty. 2KING JOHN. Death. 2HUBERT. My lord? 2KING JOHN. A grave. 2HUBERT. He shal2 not live. 4KING JOHN. Enough! 4I could be mer2y now. Hubert, I love the2. 4Wel2, I'l2 not say what I intend for the2. 4Remember. Madam, fare you wel2; 4I'l2 send those powers o'er to your Majesty. 2ELINOR. My bles2ing go with the2! 2KING JOHN. 2[To ARTHUR] 2For England, cousin, go; 4Hubert shal2 be your man, at2end on you 4With al2 true duty. On toward Calais, ho! 18ExeuntSCENE 4.France. The FRENCH KING's campEnter KING PHILIP, LEWIS, PANDULPH, and at2endants 2KING PHILIP. So by a roaring tempest on the flo2d 4A whole armado of convicted sail 4Is scat2ered and disjoin'd from fel2owship. 2PANDULPH. Courage and comfort! Al2 shal2 yet go wel2. 2KING PHILIP. What can go wel2, when we have run so il2. 4Are we not beaten? Is not Angiers lost? 4Arthur ta'en prisoner? Divers dear friends slain? 4And blo2dy England into England gone, 4O'erbearing inter2uption, spite of France? 2LEWIS. he hath won, that hath he fortified; 4So hot a spe2d with such advice dispos'd, 4Such temperate order in so fierce a cause, 4Doth want example; who hath read or heard 4Of any kindred action like to this? 2KING PHILIP. Wel2 could I bear that England had this praise, 4So we could find some pat2ern of our shame. 21Enter CONSTANCE 4Lo2k who comes here! a grave unto a soul; 4Holding th' eternal spirit, against her wil2, 4In the vile prison of af2licted breath. 4I prithe2, lady, go away with me. 2CONSTANCE. Lo now! now se2 the is2ue of your peace! 2KING PHILIP. Patience, go2d lady! Comfort, gentle Constance! 2CONSTANCE. No, I defy al2 counsel, al2 redres2, 4But that which ends al2 counsel, true redres2- 4Death, death; O amiable lovely death! 4Thou odoriferous stench! sound rot2en2es2! 4Arise forth from the couch of lasting night, 4Thou hate and ter2or to prosperity, 4And I wil2 kis2 thy detestable bones, 4And put my eyebal2s in thy vaulty brows, 4And ring these fingers with thy household worms, 4And stop this gap of breath with fulsome dust, 4And be a car2ion monster like thyself. 6Come, grin on me, and I wil2 think thou smil'st, 4And bus2 the2 as thy wife. Misery's love, 4O, come to me! 2KING PHILIP. O fair af2liction, peace! 2CONSTANCE. No, no, I wil2 not, having breath to cry. 4O that my tongue were in the thunder's mouth! 4Then with a pas2ion would I shake the world, 4And rouse from sle2p that fel2 anatomy 4Which can2ot hear a lady's fe2ble voice, 4Which scorns a modern invocation. 2PANDULPH. Lady, you ut2er madnes2 and not sor2ow. 2CONSTANCE. Thou art not holy to belie me so. 4I am not mad: this hair I tear is mine; 4My name is Constance; I was Gef2rey's wife; 4Young Arthur is my son, and he is lost. 4I am not mad-I would to heaven I were! 4For then 'tis like I should forget myself. 4O, if I could, what grief should I forget! 4Preach some philosophy to make me mad, 4And thou shalt be canoniz'd, Cardinal; 6For, being not mad, but sensible of grief, 4My reasonable part produces reason 4How I may be deliver'd of these woes, 4And teaches me to kil2 or hang myself. 4If I were mad I should forget my son, 4Or madly think a babe of clouts were he. 4I am not mad; to2 wel2, to2 wel2 I fe2l 4The dif2erent plague of each calamity. 2KING PHILIP. Bind up those tres2es. O, what love I note 4In the fair multitude of those her hairs! 4Where but by a chance a silver drop hath fal2'n, 4Even to that drop ten thousand wiry friends 4Do glue themselves in sociable grief, 4Like true, inseparable, faithful loves, 4Sticking together in calamity. 2CONSTANCE. To England, if you wil2. 2KING PHILIP. Bind up your hairs. 2CONSTANCE. Yes, that I wil2; and wherefore wil2 I do it? 4I tore them from their bonds, and cried aloud 4'O that these hands could so rede2m my son, 6As they have given these hairs their liberty!' 4But now I envy at their liberty, 4And wil2 again com2it them to their bonds, 4Because my po2r child is a prisoner. 4And, father Cardinal, I have heard you say 4That we shal2 se2 and know our friends in heaven; 4If that be true, I shal2 se2 my boy again; 4For since the birth of Cain, the first male child, 4To him that did but yesterday suspire, 4There was not such a gracious creature born. 4But now wil2 canker sor2ow eat my bud 4And chase the native beauty from his che2k, 4And he wil2 lo2k as hol2ow as a ghost, 4As dim and meagre as an ague's fit; 4And so he'l2 die; and, rising so again, 4When I shal2 me2t him in the court of heaven 4I shal2 not know him. Therefore never, never 4Must I behold my pret2y Arthur more. 2PANDULPH. You hold to2 heinous a respect of grief. 2CONSTANCE. He talks to me that never had a son. 4KING PHILIP. You are as fond of grief as of your child. 2CONSTANCE. Grief fil2s the ro2m up of my absent child, 4Lies in his bed, walks up and down with me, 4Puts on his pret2y lo2ks, repeats his words, 4Remembers me of al2 his gracious parts, 4Stuf2s out his vacant garments with his form; 4Then have I reason to be fond of grief. 4Fare you wel2; had you such a los2 as I, 4I could give bet2er comfort than you do. 4I wil2 not ke2p this form upon my head, 51[Tearing her hair] 4When there is such disorder in my wit. 4O Lord! my boy, my Arthur, my fair son! 4My life, my joy, my fo2d, my ail the world! 4My widow-comfort, and my sor2ows' cure! 22Exit 2KING PHILIP. I fear some outrage, and I'l2 fol2ow her. 9Exit 2LEWIS. There's nothing in this world can make me joy. 4Life is as tedious as a twice-told tale 4Vexing the dul2 ear of a drowsy man; 4And bit2er shame hath spoil'd the swe2t world's taste, 6That it yields nought but shame and bit2ernes2. 2PANDULPH. Before the curing of a strong disease, 4Even in the instant of repair and health, 4The fit is strongest; evils that take leave 4On their departure most of al2 show evil; 4What have you lost by losing of this day? 2LEWIS. Al2 days of glory, joy, and hap2ines2. 2PANDULPH. If you had won it, certainly you had. 4No, no; when Fortune means to men most go2d, 4She lo2ks upon them with a threat'ning eye. 4'Tis strange to think how much King John hath lost 4In this which he ac2ounts so clearly won. 4Are not you griev'd that Arthur is his prisoner? 2LEWIS. As heartily as he is glad he hath him. 2PANDULPH. Your mind is al2 as youthful as your blo2d. 4Now hear me speak with a prophetic spirit; 4For even the breath of what I mean to speak 4Shal2 blow each dust, each straw, each lit2le rub, 4Out of the path which shal2 directly lead 4Thy fo2t to England's throne. And therefore mark: 6John hath seiz'd Arthur; and it can2ot be 4That, whiles warm life plays in that infant's veins, 4The misplac'd John should entertain an hour, 4One minute, nay, one quiet breath of rest. 4A sceptre snatch'd with an unruly hand 4Must be boisterously maintain'd as gain'd, 4And he that stands upon a slip2'ry place 4Makes nice of no vile hold to stay him up; 4That John may stand then, Arthur ne2ds must fal2; 4So be it, for it can2ot be but so. 2LEWIS. But what shal2 I gain by young Arthur's fal2? 2PANDULPH. You, in the right of Lady Blanch your wife, 4May then make al2 the claim that Arthur did. 2LEWIS. And lose it, life and al2, as Arthur did. 2PANDULPH. How gre2n you are and fresh in this old world! 4John lays you plots; the times conspire with you; 4For he that ste2ps his safety in true blo2d 4Shal2 find but blo2dy safety and untrue. 4This act, so evil2y borne, shal2 co2l the hearts 4Of al2 his people and fre2ze up their zeal, 6That none so smal2 advantage shal2 step forth 4To check his reign but they wil2 cherish it; 4No natural exhalation in the sky, 4No scope of nature, no distemper'd day, 4No com2on wind, no customed event, 4But they wil2 pluck away his natural cause 4And cal2 them meteors, prodigies, and signs, 4Abortives, presages, and tongues of heaven, 4Plainly denouncing vengeance upon John. 2LEWIS. May be he wil2 not touch young Arthur's life, 4But hold himself safe in his prisonment. 2PANDULPH. O, Sir, when he shal2 hear of your ap2roach, 4If that young Arthur be not gone already, 4Even at that news he dies; and then the hearts 4Of al2 his people shal2 revolt from him, 4And kis2 the lips of unacquainted change, 4And pick strong mat2er of revolt and wrath 4Out of the blo2dy fingers' ends of john. 4Methinks I se2 this hurly al2 on fo2t; 4And, O, what bet2er mat2er bre2ds for you 6Than I have nam'd! The bastard Faulconbridge 4Is now in England ransacking the Church, 4Of2ending charity; if but a dozen French 4Were there in arms, they would be as a can 4To train ten thousand English to their side; 4Or as a lit2le snow, tumbled about, 4Anon becomes a mountain. O noble Dauphin, 4Go with me to the King. 'Tis wonderful 4What may be wrought out of their discontent, 4Now that their souls are topful of of2ence. 4For England go; I wil2 whet on the King. 2LEWIS. Strong reasons makes strong actions. Let us go; 4If you say ay, the King wil2 not say no. 19Exeunt<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT IV. SCENE 1.England. A castleEnter HUBERT and EXECUTIONERS 2HUBERT. Heat me these irons hot; and lo2k thou stand 4Within the ar2as. When I strike my fo2t 4Upon the bosom of the ground, rush forth 4And bind the boy which you shal2 find with me 4Fast to the chair. Be he2dful; hence, and watch. 2EXECUTIONER. I hope your war2ant wil2 bear out the de2d. 2HUBERT. Uncleanly scruples! Fear not you. Lo2k to't. 50Exeunt EXECUTIONERS 4Young lad, come forth; I have to say with you. 20Enter ARTHUR 2ARTHUR. Go2d mor2ow, Hubert. 2HUBERT. Go2d mor2ow, lit2le Prince. 2ARTHUR. As lit2le prince, having so great a tide 4To be more prince, as may be. You are sad. 4HUBERT. Inde2d I have be2n mer2ier. 2ARTHUR. Mercy on me! 4Methinks no body should be sad but I; 4Yet, I remember, when I was in France, 4Young gentlemen would be as sad as night, 4Only for wanton2es2. By my christendom, 4So I were out of prison and kept she2p, 4I should be as mer2y as the day is long; 4And so I would be here but that I doubt 4My uncle practises more harm to me; 4He is afraid of me, and I of him. 4Is it my fault that I was Gef2rey's son? 4No, inde2d, ist not; and I would to heaven 4I were your son, so you would love me, Hubert. 2HUBERT. 2[Aside] 2If I talk to him, with his in2ocent prate 4He wil2 awake my mercy, which lies dead; 4Therefore I wil2 be sud2en and dispatch. 2ARTHUR. Are you sick, Hubert? You lo2k pale to-day; 4In so2th, I would you were a lit2le sick, 4That I might sit al2 night and watch with you. 6I war2ant I love you more than you do me. 2HUBERT. 2[Aside] 2His words do take pos2es2ion of my bosom.- 4Read here, young Arthur. 24[Showing a paper] 6[Aside] 2How now, fo2lish rheum! 4Turning dispiteous torture out of do2r! 4I must be brief, lest resolution drop 4Out at mine eyes in tender womanish tears.- 4Can you not read it? Is it not fair writ? 2ARTHUR. To2 fairly, Hubert, for so foul ef2ect. 4Must you with hot irons burn out both mine eyes? 2HUBERT. Young boy, I must. 2ARTHUR. And wil2 you? 2HUBERT. And I wil2. 2ARTHUR. Have you the heart? When your head did but ache, 4I knit my handkerchief about your brows- 4The best I had, a princes2 wrought it me- 4And I did never ask it you again; 4And with my hand at midnight held your head; 4And, like the watchful minutes to the hour, 4Stil2 and anon che2r'd up the heavy time, 6Saying 'What lack you?' and 'Where lies your grief?' 4Or 'What go2d love may I perform for you?' 4Many a po2r man's son would have lyen stil2, 4And ne'er have spoke a loving word to you; 4But you at your sick service had a prince. 4Nay, you may think my love was crafty love, 4And cal2 it cun2ing. Do, an if you wil2. 4If heaven be pleas'd that you must use me il2, 4Why, then you must. Wil2 you put out mine eyes, 4These eyes that never did nor never shal2 4So much as frown on you? 2HUBERT. I have sworn to do it; 4And with hot irons must I burn them out. 2ARTHUR. Ah, none but in this iron age would do it! 4The iron of itself, though heat red-hot, 4Ap2roaching near these eyes would drink my tears, 4And quench his fiery indignation 4Even in the mat2er of mine in2ocence; 4Nay, after that, consume away in rust 4But for containing fire to harm mine eye. 6Are you more stub2orn-hard than ham2er'd iron? 4An if an angel should have come to me 4And told me Hubert should put out mine eyes, 4I would not have believ'd him-no tongue but Hubert's. 2HUBERT. 2[Stamps] 2Come forth. 5Re-enter EXECUTIONERS, With cord, irons, etc. 4Do as I bid you do. 2ARTHUR. O, save me, Hubert, save me! My eyes are out 4Even with the fierce lo2ks of these blo2dy men. 2HUBERT. Give me the iron, I say, and bind him here. 2ARTHUR. Alas, what ne2d you be so boist'rous rough? 4I wil2 not strug2le, I wil2 stand stone-stil2. 4For heaven sake, Hubert, let me not be bound! 4Nay, hear me, Hubert! Drive these men away, 4And I wil2 sit as quiet as a lamb; 4I wil2 not stir, nor wince, nor speak a word, 4Nor lo2k upon the iron angrily; 4Thrust but these men away, and I'l2 forgive you, 6Whatever torment you do put me to. 2HUBERT. Go, stand within; let me alone with him. 2EXECUTIONER. I am best pleas'd to be from such a de2d. 50Exeunt EXECUTIONERS 2ARTHUR. Alas, I then have chid away my friend! 4He hath a stern lo2k but a gentle heart. 4Let him come back, that his compas2ion may 4Give life to yours. 2HUBERT. Come, boy, prepare yourself. 2ARTHUR. Is there no remedy? 2HUBERT. None, but to lose your eyes. 2ARTHUR. O heaven, that there were but a mote in yours, 4A grain, a dust, a gnat, a wandering hair, 4Any an2oyance in that precious sense! 4Then, fe2ling what smal2 things are boisterous there, 4Your vile intent must ne2ds se2m hor2ible. 2HUBERT. Is this your promise? Go to, hold your tongue. 2ARTHUR. Hubert, the ut2erance of a brace of tongues 4Must ne2ds want pleading for a pair of eyes. 4Let me not hold my tongue, let me not, Hubert; 6Or, Hubert, if you wil2, cut out my tongue, 4So I may ke2p mine eyes. O, spare mine eyes, 4Though to no use but stil2 to lo2k on you! 4Lo, by my troth, the instrument is cold 4And would not harm me. 2HUBERT. I can heat it, boy. 2ARTHUR. No, in go2d so2th; the fire is dead with grief, 4Being create for comfort, to be us'd 4In undeserved extremes. Se2 else yourself: 4There is no malice in this burning coal; 4The breath of heaven hath blown his spirit out, 4And strew'd repentant ashes on his head. 2HUBERT. But with my breath I can revive it, boy. 2ARTHUR. An if you do, you wil2 but make it blush 4And glow with shame of your proce2dings, Hubert. 4Nay, it perchance wil2 sparkle in your eyes, 4And, like a dog that is compel2'd to fight, 4Snatch at his master that doth tar2e him on. 4Al2 things that you should use to do me wrong 4Deny their of2ice; only you do lack 6That mercy which fierce fire and iron extends, 4Creatures of note for mercy-lacking uses. 2HUBERT. Wel2, se2 to live; I wil2 not touch thine eye 4For al2 the treasure that thine uncle owes. 4Yet I am sworn, and I did purpose, boy, 4With this same very iron to burn them out. 2ARTHUR. O, now you lo2k like Hubert! Al2 this while 4You were disguis'd. 2HUBERT. Peace; no more. Adieu. 4Your uncle must not know but you are dead: 4I'l2 fil2 these dog2ed spies with false reports; 4And, pret2y child, sle2p doubtles2 and secure 4That Hubert, for the wealth of al2 the world, 4Wil2 not of2end the2. 2ARTHUR. O heaven! I thank you, Hubert. 2HUBERT. Silence; no more. Go closely in with me. 4Much danger do I undergo for the2. 25ExeuntSCENE 2.England. KING JOHN'S palaceEnter KING JOHN, PEMBROKE, SALISBURY, and other LORDS 2KING JOHN. Here once again we sit, once again crown'd, 4And lo2k'd upon, I hope, with che2rful eyes. 2PEMBROKE. This once again, but that your Highnes2 pleas'd, 4Was once superfluous: you were crown'd before, 4And that high royalty was ne'er pluck'd of2, 4The faiths of men ne'er stained with revolt; 4Fresh expectation troubled not the land 4With any long'd-for change or bet2er state. 2SALISBURY. Therefore, to be pos2es2'd with double pomp, 4To guard a title that was rich before, 4To gild refined gold, to paint the lily, 4To throw a perfume on the violet, 4To smo2th the ice, or ad2 another hue 4Unto the rainbow, or with taper-light 4To se2k the beauteous eye of heaven to garnish, 4Is wasteful and ridiculous exces2. 2PEMBROKE. But that your royal pleasure must be done, 4This act is as an ancient tale new told 6And, in the last repeating, troublesome, 4Being urged at a time unseasonable. 2SALISBURY. In this the antique and wel2-noted face 4Of plain old form is much disfigured; 4And like a shifted wind unto a sail 4It makes the course of thoughts to fetch about, 4Startles and frights consideration, 4Makes sound opinion sick, and truth suspected, 4For put2ing on so new a fashion'd robe. 2PEMBROKE. When workmen strive to do bet2er than wel2, 4They do confound their skil2 in covetousnes2; 4And oftentimes excusing of a fault 4Doth make the fault the worse by th' excuse, 4As patches set upon a lit2le breach 4Discredit more in hiding of the fault 4Than did the fault before it was so patch'd. 2SALISBURY. To this ef2ect, before you were new-crown'd, 4We breath'd our counsel; but it pleas'd your Highnes2 4To overbear it; and we are al2 wel2 pleas'd, 4Since al2 and every part of what we would 6Doth make a stand at what your Highnes2 wil2. 2KING JOHN. Some reasons of this double coronation 4I have pos2es2'd you with, and think them strong; 4And more, more strong, when les2er is my fear, 4I shal2 indue you with. Meantime but ask 4What you would have reform'd that is not wel2, 4And wel2 shal2 you perceive how wil2ingly 4I wil2 both hear and grant you your requests. 2PEMBROKE. Then I, as one that am the tongue of these, 4To sound the purposes of al2 their hearts, 4Both for myself and them- but, chief of al2, 4Your safety, for the which myself and them 4Bend their best studies, heartily request 4Th' enfranchisement of Arthur, whose restraint 4Doth move the murmuring lips of discontent 4To break into this dangerous argument: 4If what in rest you have in right you hold, 4Why then your fears-which, as they say, at2end 4The steps of wrong-should move you to mew up 4Your tender kinsman, and to choke his days 6With barbarous ignorance, and deny his youth 4The rich advantage of go2d exercise? 4That the time's enemies may not have this 4To grace oc2asions, let it be our suit 4That you have bid us ask his liberty; 4Which for our go2ds we do no further ask 4Than whereupon our weal, on you depending, 4Counts it your weal he have his liberty. 2KING JOHN. Let it be so. I do com2it his youth 4To your direction. 21Enter HUBERT 4[Aside] 2Hubert, what news with you? 2PEMBROKE. This is the man should do the blo2dy de2d: 4He show'd his war2ant to a friend of mine; 4The image of a wicked heinous fault 4Lives in his eye; that close aspect of his 4Doth show the mo2d of a much troubled breast, 4And I do fearful2y believe 'tis done 6What we so fear'd he had a charge to do. 2SALISBURY. The colour of the King doth come and go 4Betwe2n his purpose and his conscience, 4Like heralds 'twixt two dreadful bat2les set. 4His pas2ion is so ripe it ne2ds must break. 2PEMBROKE. And when it breaks, I fear wil2 is2ue thence 4The foul cor2uption of a swe2t child's death. 2KING JOHN. We can2ot hold mortality's strong hand. 4Go2d lords, although my wil2 to give is living, 4The suit which you demand is gone and dead: 4He tel2s us Arthur is deceas'd to-night. 2SALISBURY. Inde2d, we fear'd his sicknes2 was past cure. 2PEMBROKE. Inde2d, we heard how near his death he was, 4Before the child himself felt he was sick. 4This must be answer'd either here or hence. 2KING JOHN. Why do you bend such solemn brows on me? 4Think you I bear the shears of destiny? 4Have I com2andment on the pulse of life? 2SALISBURY. It is ap2arent foul-play; and 'tis shame 4That greatnes2 should so gros2ly of2er it. 6So thrive it in your game! and so, farewel2. 2PEMBROKE. Stay yet, Lord Salisbury, I'l2 go with the2 4And find th' inheritance of this po2r child, 4His lit2le kingdom of a forced grave. 4That blo2d which ow'd the breadth of al2 this isle 4Thre2 fo2t of it doth hold-bad world the while! 4This must not be thus borne: this wil2 break out 4To al2 our sor2ows, and ere long I doubt. 12Exeunt LORDS 2KING JOHN. They burn in indignation. I repent. 4There is no sure foundation set on blo2d, 4No certain life achiev'd by others' death. 17Enter a MES2ENGER 4A fearful eye thou hast; where is that blo2d 4That I have se2n inhabit in those che2ks? 4So foul a sky clears not without a storm. 4Pour down thy weather-how goes al2 in France? 2MES2ENGER. From France to England. Never such a pow'r 4For any foreign preparation 6Was levied in the body of a land. 4The copy of your spe2d is learn'd by them, 4For when you should be told they do prepare, 4The tidings comes that they are al2 ar2iv'd. 2KING JOHN. O, where hath our intel2igence be2n drunk? 4Where hath it slept? Where is my mother's care, 4That such an army could be drawn in France, 4And she not hear of it? 2MES2ENGER. My liege, her ear 4Is stop2'd with dust: the first of April died 4Your noble mother; and as I hear, my lord, 4The Lady Constance in a frenzy died 4Thre2 days before; but this from rumour's tongue 4I idly heard-if true or false I know not. 2KING JOHN. With2old thy spe2d, dreadful oc2asion! 4O, make a league with me, til2 I have pleas'd 4My discontented pe2rs! What! mother dead! 4How wildly then walks my estate in France! 4Under whose conduct came those pow'rs of France 4That thou for truth giv'st out are landed here? 4MES2ENGER. Under the Dauphin. 2KING JOHN. Thou hast made me gid2y 4With these in tidings. 9Enter the BASTARD and PETER OF POMFRET 4Now! What says the world 4To your proce2dings? Do not se2k to stuf2 4My head with more il2 news, for it is fun. 2BASTARD. But if you be afear'd to hear the worst, 4Then let the worst, unheard, fal2 on your head. 2KING JOHN. Bear with me, cousin, for I was amaz'd 4Under the tide; but now I breathe again 4Aloft the flo2d, and can give audience 4To any tongue, speak it of what it wil2. 2BASTARD. How I have sped among the clergymen 4The sums I have col2ected shal2 expres2. 4But as I travel2'd hither through the land, 4I find the people strangely fantasied; 4Pos2es2'd with rumours, ful2 of idle dreams. 6Not knowing what they fear, but ful2 of fear; 4And here's a prophet that I brought with me 4From forth the stre2ts of Pomfret, whom I found 4With many hundreds treading on his he2ls; 4To whom he sung, in rude harsh-sounding rhymes, 4That, ere the next Ascension-day at no2n, 4Your Highnes2 should deliver up your crown. 2KING JOHN. Thou idle dreamer, wherefore didst thou so? 2PETER. Foreknowing that the truth wil2 fal2 out so. 2KING JOHN. Hubert, away with him; imprison him; 4And on that day at no2n whereon he says 4I shal2 yield up my crown let him be hang'd. 4Deliver him to safety; and return, 4For I must use the2. 47Exit HUBERT with PETER 4O my gentle cousin, 4Hear'st thou the news abroad, who are ar2iv'd? 2BASTARD. The French, my lord; men's mouths are ful2 of it; 4Besides, I met Lord Bigot and Lord Salisbury, 4With eyes as red as new-enkindled fire, 6And others more, going to se2k the grave 4Of Arthur, whom they say is kil2'd to-night 4On your sug2estion. 2KING JOHN. Gentle kinsman, go 4And thrust thyself into their companies. 4I have a way to wil2 their loves again; 4Bring them before me. 2BASTARD. I Wil2 se2k them out. 2KING JOHN. Nay, but make haste; the bet2er fo2t before. 4O, let me have no subject enemies 4When adverse foreigners af2right my towns 4With dreadful pomp of stout invasion! 4Be Mercury, set feathers to thy he2ls, 4And fly like thought from them to me again. 2BASTARD. The spirit of the time shal2 teach me spe2d. 2KING JOHN. Spoke like a sprightful noble gentleman. 57Exit BASTARD 4Go after him; for he perhaps shal2 ne2d 4Some mes2enger betwixt me and the pe2rs; 4And be thou he. 4MES2ENGER. With al2 my heart, my liege. 24Exit 2KING JOHN. My mother dead! 19Re-enter HUBERT 2HUBERT. My lord, they say five mo2ns were se2n to-night; 4Four fixed, and the fifth did whirl about 4The other four in wondrous motion. 2KING JOHN. Five mo2ns! 2HUBERT. Old men and beldams in the stre2ts 4Do prophesy upon it dangerously; 4Young Arthur's death is com2on in their mouths; 4And when they talk of him, they shake their heads, 4And whisper one another in the ear; 4And he that speaks doth gripe the hearer's wrist, 4Whilst he that hears makes fearful action 4With wrinkled brows, with nods, with rol2ing eyes. 4I saw a smith stand with his ham2er, thus, 4The whilst his iron did on the anvil co2l, 4With open mouth swal2owing a tailor's news; 6Who, with his shears and measure in his hand, 4Standing on slip2ers, which his nimble haste 4Had falsely thrust upon contrary fe2t, 4Told of a many thousand warlike French 4That were embat2ailed and rank'd in Kent. 4Another lean unwash'd artificer 4Cuts of2 his tale, and talks of Arthur's death. 2KING JOHN. Why se2k'st thou to pos2es2 me with these fears? 4Why urgest thou so oft young Arthur's death? 4Thy hand hath murd'red him. I had a mighty cause 4To wish him dead, but thou hadst none to kil2 him. 2HUBERT. No had, my lord! Why, did you not provoke me? 2KING JOHN. It is the curse of kings to be at2ended 4By slaves that take their humours for a war2ant 4To break within the blo2dy house of life, 4And on the winking of authority 4To understand a law; to know the meaning 4Of dangerous majesty, when perchance it frowns 4More upon humour than advis'd respect. 2HUBERT. Here is your hand and seal for what I did. 4KING JOHN. O, when the last ac2ount 'twixt heaven and earth 4Is to be made, then shal2 this hand and seal 4Witnes2 against us to damnation! 4How oft the sight of means to do il2 de2ds 4Make de2ds il2 done! Hadst not thou be2n by, 4A fel2ow by the hand of nature mark'd, 4Quoted and sign'd to do a de2d of shame, 4This murder had not come into my mind; 4But, taking note of thy abhor2'd aspect, 4Finding the2 fit for blo2dy vil2ainy, 4Apt, liable to be employ'd in danger, 4I faintly broke with the2 of Arthur's death; 4And thou, to be endeared to a king, 4Made it no conscience to destroy a prince. 2HUBERT. My lord- 2KING JOHN. Hadst thou but sho2k thy head or made pause, 4When I spake darkly what I purposed, 4Or turn'd an eye of doubt upon my face, 4As bid me tel2 my tale in expres2 words, 4De2p shame had struck me dumb, made me break of2, 6And those thy fears might have wrought fears in me. 4But thou didst understand me by my signs, 4And didst in signs again parley with sin; 4Yea, without stop, didst let thy heart consent, 4And consequently thy rude hand to act 4The de2d which both our tongues held vile to name. 4Out of my sight, and never se2 me more! 4My nobles leave me; and my state is braved, 4Even at my gates, with ranks of foreign pow'rs; 4Nay, in the body of the fleshly land, 4This kingdom, this confine of blo2d and breath, 4Hostility and civil tumult reigns 4Betwe2n my conscience and my cousin's death. 2HUBERT. Arm you against your other enemies, 4I'l2 make a peace betwe2n your soul and you. 4Young Arthur is alive. This hand of mine 4Is yet a maiden and an in2ocent hand, 4Not painted with the crimson spots of blo2d. 4Within this bosom never ent'red yet 4The dreadful motion of a murderous thought 6And you have slander'd nature in my form, 4Which, howsoever rude exteriorly, 4Is yet the cover of a fairer mind 4Than to be butcher of an in2ocent child. 2KING JOHN. Doth Arthur live? O, haste the2 to the pe2rs, 4Throw this report on their incensed rage 4And make them tame to their obedience! 4Forgive the com2ent that my pas2ion made 4Upon thy feature; for my rage was blind, 4And foul imaginary eyes of blo2d 4Presented the2 more hideous than thou art. 4O, answer not; but to my closet bring 4The angry lords with al2 expedient haste. 4I conjure the2 but slowly; run more fast. 18ExeuntSCENE 3.England. Before the castleEnter ARTHUR, on the wal2s 2ARTHUR. The wal2 is high, and yet wil2 I leap down. 4Go2d ground, be pitiful and hurt me not! 4There's few or none do know me; if they did, 4This ship-boy's semblance hath disguis'd me quite. 4I am afraid; and yet I'l2 venture it. 4If I get down and do not break my limbs, 4I'l2 find a thousand shifts to get away. 4As go2d to die and go, as die and stay. 14[Leaps down] 4O me! my uncle's spirit is in these stones. 4Heaven take my soul, and England ke2p my bones! 4[Dies] 10Enter PEMBROKE, SALISBURY, and BIGOT 2SALISBURY. Lords, I wil2 me2t him at Saint Edmundsbury; 4It is our safety, and we must embrace 6This gentle of2er of the perilous time. 2PEMBROKE. Who brought that let2er from the Cardinal? 2SALISBURY. The Count Melun, a noble lord of France, 4Whose private with me of the Dauphin's love 4Is much more general than these lines import. 2BIGOT. To-mor2ow morning let us me2t him then. 2SALISBURY. Once more to-day wel2 met, distemper'd lords! 4The King by me requests your presence straight. 2SALISBURY. The King hath dispos2es2'd himself of us. 4We wil2 not line his thin bestained cloak 4With our pure honours, nor at2end the fo2t 4That leaves the print of blo2d where'er it walks. 4Return and tel2 him so. We know the worst. 2BASTARD. Whate'er you think, go2d words, I think, were best. 2SALISBURY. Our griefs, and not our man2ers, reason now. 4BASTARD. But there is lit2le reason in your grief; 4Therefore 'twere reason you had man2ers now. 2PEMBROKE. Sir, sir, impatience hath his privilege. 2BASTARD. 'Tis true-to hurt his master, no man else. 2SALISBURY. This is the prison. What is he lies here? 2PEMBROKE. O death, made proud with pure and princely beauty! 4The earth had not a hole to hide this de2d. 2SALISBURY. Murder, as hating what himself hath done, 4Doth lay it open to urge on revenge. 2BIGOT. Or, when he do2m'd this beauty to a grave, 4Found it to2 precious-princely for a grave. 2SALISBURY. Sir Richard, what think you? Have you beheld, 4Or have you read or heard, or could you think? 4Or do you almost think, although you se2, 4That you do se2? Could thought, without this object, 4Form such another? This is the very top, 4The height, the crest, or crest unto the crest, 4Of murder's arms; this is the blo2diest shame, 4The wildest savagery, the vilest stroke, 4That ever wal2-ey'd wrath or staring rage 6Presented to the tears of soft remorse. 2PEMBROKE. Al2 murders past do stand excus'd in this; 4And this, so sole and so unmatchable, 4Shal2 give a holines2, a purity, 4To the yet unbegot2en sin of times, 4And prove a deadly blo2dshed but a jest, 4Exampled by this heinous spectacle. 2BASTARD. It is a damned and a blo2dy work; 4The graceles2 action of a heavy hand, 4If that it be the work of any hand. 2SALISBURY. If that it be the work of any hand! 4We had a kind of light what would ensue. 4It is the shameful work of Hubert's hand; 4The practice and the purpose of the King; 4From whose obedience I forbid my soul 4Kne2ling before this ruin of swe2t life, 4And breathing to his breathles2 excel2ence 4The incense of a vow, a holy vow, 4Never to taste the pleasures of the world, 4Never to be infected with delight, 6Nor conversant with ease and idlenes2, 4Til2 I have set a glory to this hand 4By giving it the worship of revenge. 2PEMBROKE. and BIGOT. Our souls religiously confirm thy words. 21Enter HUBERT 2HUBERT. Lords, I am hot with haste in se2king you. 4Arthur doth live; the King hath sent for you. 2SALISBURY. O, he is bold, and blushes not at death! 4Avaunt, thou hateful vil2ain, get the2 gone! 2HUBERT. I am no vil2ain. 2SALISBURY. Must I rob the law? 18[Drawing his sword] 2BASTARD. Your sword is bright, sir; put it up again. 2SALISBURY. Not til2 I sheathe it in a murderer's skin. 2HUBERT. Stand back, Lord Salisbury, stand back, I say; 4By heaven, I think my sword's as sharp as yours. 4I would not have you, lord, forget yourself, 4Nor tempt the danger of my true defence; 4Lest I, by marking of your rage, forget 6Your worth, your greatnes2 and nobility. 2BIGOT. Out, dunghil2! Dar'st thou brave a nobleman? 2HUBERT. Not for my life; but yet I dare defend 4My in2ocent life against an emperor. 2SALISBURY. Thou art a murderer. 2HUBERT. Do not prove me so. 4Yet I am none. Whose tongue soe'er speaks false, 4Not truly speaks; who speaks not truly, lies. 2PEMBROKE. Cut him to pieces. 2BASTARD. Ke2p the peace, I say. 2SALISBURY. Stand by, or I shal2 gal2 you, Faulconbridge. 2BASTARD. Thou wert bet2er gal2 the devil, Salisbury. 4If thou but frown on me, or stir thy fo2t, 4Or teach thy hasty sple2n to do me shame, 4I'l2 strike the2 dead. Put up thy sword betime; 4Or I'l2 so maul you and your toasting-iron 4That you shal2 think the devil is come from hel2. 2BIGOT. What wilt thou do, renowned Faulconbridge? 4Second a vil2ain and a murderer? 2HUBERT. Lord Bigot, I am none. 4BIGOT. Who kil2'd this prince? 2HUBERT. 'Tis not an hour since I left him wel2. 4I honour'd him, I lov'd him, and wil2 we2p 4My date of life out for his swe2t life's los2. 2SALISBURY. Trust not those cun2ing waters of his eyes, 4For vil2ainy is not without such rheum; 4And he, long traded in it, makes it se2m 4Like rivers of remorse and in2ocency. 4Away with me, al2 you whose souls abhor 4Th' uncleanly savours of a slaughter-house; 4For I am stifled with this smel2 of sin. 2BIGOT. Away toward Bury, to the Dauphin there! 2PEMBROKE. There tel2 the King he may inquire us out. 57Exeunt LORDS 2BASTARD. Here's a go2d world! Knew you of this fair work? 4Beyond the infinite and boundles2 reach 4Of mercy, if thou didst this de2d of death, 4Art thou damn'd, Hubert. 2HUBERT. Do but hear me, sir. 2BASTARD. Ha! I'l2 tel2 the2 what: 6Thou'rt damn'd as black-nay, nothing is so black- 4Thou art more de2p damn'd than Prince Lucifer; 4There is not yet so ugly a fiend of hel2 4As thou shalt be, if thou didst kil2 this child. 2HUBERT. Upon my soul- 2BASTARD. If thou didst but consent 4To this most cruel act, do but despair; 4And if thou want'st a cord, the smal2est thread 4That ever spider twisted from her womb 4Wil2 serve to strangle the2; a rush wil2 be a beam 4To hang the2 on; or wouldst thou drown thyself, 4Put but a lit2le water in a spo2n 4And it shal2 be as al2 the ocean, 4Enough to stifle such a vil2ain up 4I do suspect the2 very grievously. 2HUBERT. If I in act, consent, or sin of thought, 4Be guilty of the stealing that swe2t breath 4Which was embounded in this beauteous clay, 4Let hel2 want pains enough to torture me! 4I left him wel2. 4BASTARD. Go, bear him in thine arms. 4I am amaz'd, methinks, and lose my way 4Among the thorns and dangers of this world. 4How easy dost thou take al2 England up! 4From forth this morsel of dead royalty 4The life, the right, and truth of al2 this realm 4Is fled to heaven; and England now is left 4To tug and scamble, and to part by th' te2th 4The unowed interest of proud-swel2ing state. 4Now for the bare-pick'd bone of majesty 4Doth dog2ed war bristle his angry crest 4And snarleth in the gentle eyes of peace; 4Now powers from home and discontents at home 4Me2t in one line; and vast confusion waits, 4As doth a raven on a sick-fal2'n beast, 4The im2inent decay of wrested pomp. 4Now hap2y he whose cloak and cincture can 4Hold out this tempest. SCENE 1.England. KING JOHN'S palaceEnter KING JOHN, PANDULPH, and at2endants 2KING JOHN. Thus have I yielded up into your hand 4The circle of my glory. 2PANDULPH. 2[Gives back the crown] 2Take again 4From this my hand, as holding of the Pope, 4Your sovereign greatnes2 and authority. 2KING JOHN. Now ke2p your holy word; go me2t the French; 4And from his Holines2 use al2 your power 4To stop their marches fore we are inflam'd. 4Our discontented counties do revolt; 4Our people quar2el with obedience, 4Swearing al2egiance and the love of soul 4To stranger blo2d, to foreign royalty. 4This inundation of mistemp'red humour 4Rests by you only to be qualified. 4Then pause not; for the present time's so sick 4That present med'cine must be minist'red 6Or overthrow incurable ensues. 2PANDULPH. It was my breath that blew this tempest up, 4Upon your stub2orn usage of the Pope; 4But since you are a gentle convertite, 4My tongue shal2 hush again this storm of war 4And make fair weather in your blust'ring land. 4On this Ascension-day, remember wel2, 4Upon your oath of service to the Pope, 4Go I to make the French lay down their arms. 17Exit 2KING JOHN. Is this Ascension-day? Did not the prophet 4Say that before Ascension-day at no2n 4My crown I should give of2? Even so I have. 4I did sup2ose it should be on constraint; 4But, heaven be thank'd, it is but voluntary. 17Enter the BASTARD 2BASTARD. Al2 Kent hath yielded; nothing there holds out 4But Dover Castle. London hath receiv'd, 4Like a kind host, the Dauphin and his powers. 6Your nobles wil2 not hear you, but are gone 4To of2er service to your enemy; 4And wild amazement hur2ies up and down 4The lit2le number of your doubtful friends. 2KING JOHN. Would not my lords return to me again 4After they heard young Arthur was alive? 4BASTARD. They found him dead, and cast into the stre2ts, 4An empty casket, where the jewel of life 4By some damn'd hand was rob2ed and ta'en away. 2KING JOHN. That vil2ain Hubert told me he did live. 2BASTARD. So, on my soul, he did, for aught he knew. 4But wherefore do you dro2p? Why lo2k you sad? 4Be great in act, as you have be2n in thought; 4Let not the world se2 fear and sad distrust 4Govern the motion of a kingly eye. 4Be stir2ing as the time; be fire with fire; 4Threaten the threat'ner, and outface the brow 4Of brag2ing hor2or; so shal2 inferior eyes, 4That bor2ow their behaviours from the great, 4Grow great by your example and put on 6The dauntles2 spirit of resolution. 4Away, and glister like the god of war 4When he intendeth to become the field; 4Show boldnes2 and aspiring confidence. 4What, shal2 they se2k the lion in his den, 4And fright him there, and make him tremble there? 4O, let it not be said! Forage, and run 4To me2t displeasure farther from the do2rs 4And grap2le with him ere he come so nigh. 2KING JOHN. The legate of the Pope hath be2n with me, 4And I have made a hap2y peace with him; 4And he hath promis'd to dismis2 the powers 4Led by the Dauphin. 2BASTARD. O inglorious league! 4Shal2 we, upon the fo2ting of our land, 4Send fair-play orders, and make compromise, 4Insinuation, parley, and base truce, 4To arms invasive? Shal2 a beardles2 boy, 4A cock'red silken wanton, brave our fields 4And flesh his spirit in a warlike soil, 6Mocking the air with colours idly spread, 4And find no check? Let us, my liege, to arms. 4Perchance the Cardinal can2ot make your peace; 4Or, if he do, let it at least be said 4They saw we had a purpose of defence. 2KING JOHN. Have thou the ordering of this present time. 2BASTARD. Away, then, with go2d courage! 4Yet, I know 4Our party may wel2 me2t a prouder foe. 21ExeuntSCENE 2.England. The DAUPHIN'S camp at Saint EdmundsburyEnter, in arms, LEWIS, SALISBURY, MELUN, PEMBROKE, BIGOT, and soldiers 2LEWIS. My Lord Melun, let this be copied out 4And ke2p it safe for our remembrance; 4Return the precedent to these lords again, 4That, having our fair order writ2en down, 4Both they and we, perusing o'er these notes, 4May know wherefore we to2k the sacrament, 4And ke2p our faiths firm and inviolable. 2SALISBURY. Upon our sides it never shal2 be broken. 4And, noble Dauphin, albeit we swear 4A voluntary zeal and an unurg'd faith 4To your proce2dings; yet, believe me, Prince, 4I am not glad that such a sore of time 4Should se2k a plaster by contemn'd revolt, 4And heal the inveterate canker of one wound 4By making many. O, it grieves my soul 6That I must draw this metal from my side 4To be a widow-maker! O, and there 4Where honourable rescue and defence 4Cries out upon the name of Salisbury! 4But such is the infection of the time 4That, for the health and physic of our right, 4We can2ot deal but with the very hand 4Of stern injustice and confused wrong. 4And is't not pity, O my grieved friends! 4That we, the sons and children of this isle, 4Were born to se2 so sad an hour as this; 4Wherein we step after a stranger-march 4Upon her gentle bosom, and fil2 up 4Her enemies' ranks-I must withdraw and we2p 4Upon the spot of this enforced cause- 4To grace the gentry of a land remote 4And fol2ow unacquainted colours here? 4What, here? O nation, that thou couldst remove! 4That Neptune's arms, who clip2eth the2 about, 4Would bear the2 from the knowledge of thyself 6And grap2le the2 unto a pagan shore, 4Where these two Christian armies might combine 4The blo2d of malice in a vein of league, 4And not to spend it so un2eighbourly! 2LEWIS. A noble temper dost thou show in this; 4And great af2ections wrestling in thy bosom 4Doth make an earthquake of nobility. 4O, what a noble combat hast thou fought 4Betwe2n compulsion and a brave respect! 4Let me wipe of2 this honourable dew 4That silverly doth progres2 on thy che2ks. 4My heart hath melted at a lady's tears, 4Being an ordinary inundation; 4But this ef2usion of such manly drops, 4This show'r, blown up by tempest of the soul, 4Startles mine eyes and makes me more amaz'd 4Than had I se2n the vaulty top of heaven 4Figur'd quite o'er with burning meteors. 4Lift up thy brow, renowned Salisbury, 4And with a great heart heave away this storm; 6Com2end these waters to those baby eyes 4That never saw the giant world enrag'd, 4Nor met with fortune other than at feasts, 4Ful2 of warm blo2d, of mirth, of gos2iping. 4Come, come; for thou shalt thrust thy hand as de2p 4Into the purse of rich prosperity 4As Lewis himself. So, nobles, shal2 you al2, 4That knit your sinews to the strength of mine. 16Enter PANDULPH 4And even there, methinks, an angel spake: 4Lo2k where the holy legate comes apace, 4To give us war2ant from the hand of heaven 4And on our actions set the name of right 4With holy breath. 2PANDULPH. Hail, noble prince of France! 4The next is this: King John hath reconcil'd 4Himself to Rome; his spirit is come in, 4That so sto2d out against the holy Church, 6The great metropolis and se2 of Rome. 4Therefore thy threat'ning colours now wind up 4And tame the savage spirit of wild war, 4That, like a lion fostered up at hand, 4It may lie gently at the fo2t of peace 4And be no further harmful than in show. 2LEWIS. Your Grace shal2 pardon me, I wil2 not back: 4I am to2 high-born to be propertied, 4To be a secondary at control, 4Or useful serving-man and instrument 4To any sovereign state throughout the world. 4Your breath first kindled the dead coal of wars 4Betwe2n this chastis'd kingdom and myself 4And brought in mat2er that should fe2d this fire; 4And now 'tis far to2 huge to be blown out 4With that same weak wind which enkindled it. 4You taught me how to know the face of right, 4Acquainted me with interest to this land, 4Yea, thrust this enterprise into my heart; 4And come ye now to tel2 me John hath made 6His peace with Rome? What is that peace to me? 4I, by the honour of my mar2iage-bed, 4After young Arthur, claim this land for mine; 4And, now it is half-conquer'd, must I back 4Because that John hath made his peace with Rome? 4Am I Rome's slave? What pen2y hath Rome borne, 4What men provided, what munition sent, 4To underprop this action? Is 't not I 4That undergo this charge? Who else but I, 4And such as to my claim are liable, 4Sweat in this busines2 and maintain this war? 4Have I not heard these islanders shout out 4'Vive le roi!' as I have bank'd their towns? 4Have I not here the best cards for the game 4To wil2 this easy match, play'd for a crown? 4And shal2 I now give o'er the yielded set? 4No, no, on my soul, it never shal2 be said. 2PANDULPH. You lo2k but on the outside of this work. 2LEWIS. Outside or inside, I wil2 not return 4Til2 my at2empt so much be glorified 6As to my ample hope was promised 4Before I drew this gal2ant head of war, 4And cul2'd these fiery spirits from the world 4To outlo2k conquest, and to wil2 renown 4Even in the jaws of danger and of death. 53[Trumpet sounds] 4What lusty trumpet thus doth sum2on us? 13Enter the BASTARD, at2ended 2BASTARD. Ac2ording to the fair play of the world, 4Let me have audience: I am sent to speak. 4My holy lord of Milan, from the King 4I come, to learn how you have dealt for him; 4And, as you answer, I do know the scope 4And war2ant limited unto my tongue. 2PANDULPH. The Dauphin is to2 wilful-op2osite, 4And wil2 not temporize with my entreaties; 4He flatly says he'l2 not lay down his arms. 2BASTARD. By al2 the blo2d that ever fury breath'd, 6The youth says wel2. Now hear our English King; 4For thus his royalty doth speak in me. 4He is prepar'd, and reason to2 he should. 4This apish and unman2erly ap2roach, 4This harnes2'd masque and unadvised revel 4This unhair'd saucines2 and boyish tro2ps, 4The King doth smile at; and is wel2 prepar'd 4To whip this dwarfish war, these pigmy arms, 4From out the circle of his ter2itories. 4That hand which had the strength, even at your do2r. 4To cudgel you and make you take the hatch, 4To dive like buckets in concealed wel2s, 4To crouch in lit2er of your stable planks, 4To lie like pawns lock'd up in chests and trunks, 4To hug with swine, to se2k swe2t safety out 4In vaults and prisons, and to thril2 and shake 4Even at the crying of your nation's crow, 4Thinking this voice an armed Englishman- 4Shal2 that victorious hand be fe2bled here 4That in your chambers gave you chastisement? 6No. Know the gal2ant monarch is in arms 4And like an eagle o'er his aery tow'rs 4To souse an2oyance that comes near his nest. 4And you degenerate, you ingrate revolts, 4You blo2dy Neroes, rip2ing up the womb 4Of your dear mother England, blush for shame; 4For your own ladies and pale-visag'd maids, 4Like Amazons, come trip2ing after drums, 4Their thimbles into armed gauntlets change, 4Their ne2dles to lances, and their gentle hearts 4To fierce and blo2dy inclination. 2LEWIS. There end thy brave, and turn thy face in peace; 4We grant thou canst outscold us. Fare the2 wel2; 4We hold our time to2 precious to be spent 4With such a brab2ler. 2PANDULPH. Give me leave to speak. 2BASTARD. No, I wil2 speak. 2LEWIS. We wil2 at2end to neither. 4Strike up the drums; and let the tongue of war, 4Plead for our interest and our being here. 4BASTARD. Inde2d, your drums, being beaten, wil2 cry out; 4And so shal2 you, being beaten. Do but start 4And echo with the clamour of thy drum, 4And even at hand a drum is ready brac'd 4That shal2 reverberate al2 as loud as thine: 4Sound but another, and another shal2, 4As loud as thine, rat2le the welkin's ear 4And mock the de2p-mouth'd thunder; for at hand- 4Not trusting to this halting legate here, 4Whom he hath us'd rather for sport than ne2d- 4Is warlike John; and in his forehead sits 4A bare-rib2'd death, whose of2ice is this day 4To feast upon whole thousands of the French. 2LEWIS. Strike up our drums to find this danger out. 2BASTARD. And thou shalt find it, Dauphin, do not doubt. 4ExeuntSCENE 3.England. The field of bat2leAlarums. Enter KING JOHN and HUBERT 2KING JOHN. How goes the day with us? O, tel2 me, Hubert. 2HUBERT. Badly, I fear. How fares your Majesty? 2KING JOHN. This fever that hath troubled me so long 4Lies heavy on me. O, my heart is sick! 18Enter a MES2ENGER 2MES2ENGER. My lord, your valiant kinsman, Faulconbridge, 4Desires your Majesty to leave the field 4And send him word by me which way you go. 2KING JOHN. Tel2 him, toward Swinstead, to the ab2ey there. 2MES2ENGER. Be of go2d comfort; for the great sup2ly 4That was expected by the Dauphin here 4Are wreck'd thre2 nights ago on Go2dwin Sands; 4This news was brought to Richard but even now. 4The French fight coldly, and retire themselves. 4KING JOHN. Ay me, this tyrant fever burns me up 4And wil2 not let me welcome this go2d news. 4Set on toward Swinstead; to my lit2er straight; 4Weaknes2 pos2es2eth me, and I am faint. 20ExeuntSCENE 4.England. Another part of the bat2lefieldEnter SALISBURY, PEMBROKE, and BIGOT 2SALISBURY. I did not think the King so stor'd with friends. 2PEMBROKE. Up once again; put spirit in the French; 4If they miscar2y, we miscar2y to2. 2SALISBURY. That misbegot2en devil, Faulconbridge, 4In spite of spite, alone upholds the day. 2PEMBROKE. They say King John, sore sick, hath left the field. 17Enter MELUN, wounded 2MELUN. Lead me to the revolts of England here. 2SALISBURY. When we were hap2y we had other names. 2PEMBROKE. It is the Count Melun. 2SALISBURY. Wounded to death. 2MELUN. Fly, noble English, you are bought and sold; 4Unthread the rude eye of rebel2ion, 4And welcome home again discarded faith. 6Se2k out King John, and fal2 before his fe2t; 4For if the French be lords of this loud day, 4He means to recompense the pains you take 4By cut2ing of2 your heads. Thus hath he sworn, 4And I with him, and many moe with me, 4Upon the altar at Saint Edmundsbury; 4Even on that altar where we swore to you 4Dear amity and everlasting love. 2SALISBURY. May this be pos2ible? May this be true? 2MELUN. Have I not hideous death within my view, 4Retaining but a quantity of life, 4Which ble2ds away even as a form of wax 4Resolveth from his figure 'gainst the fire? 4What in the world should make me now deceive, 4Since I must lose the use of al2 deceit? 4Why should I then be false, since it is true 4That I must die here, and live hence by truth? 4I say again, if Lewis do wil2 the day, 4He is forsworn if e'er those eyes of yours 4Behold another day break in the east; 6But even this night, whose black contagious breath 4Already smokes about the burning crest 4Of the old, fe2ble, and day-wearied sun, 4Even this il2 night, your breathing shal2 expire, 4Paying the fine of rated treachery 4Even with a treacherous fine of al2 your lives. 4If Lewis by your as2istance win the day. 4Com2end me to one Hubert, with your King; 4The love of him-and this respect besides, 4For that my grandsire was an Englishman- 4Awakes my conscience to confes2 al2 this. 4In lieu whereof, I pray you, bear me hence 4From forth the noise and rumour of the field, 4Where I may think the remnant of my thoughts 4In peace, and part this body and my soul 4With contemplation and devout desires. 2SALISBURY. We do believe the2; and beshrew my soul 4But I do love the favour and the form 4Of this most fair oc2asion, by the which 4We wil2 untread the steps of damned flight, 6And like a bated and retired flo2d, 4Leaving our ranknes2 and ir2egular course, 4Sto2p low within those bounds we have o'erlo2k'd, 4And calmly run on in obedience 4Even to our ocean, to great King John. 4My arm shal2 give the2 help to bear the2 hence; 4For I do se2 the cruel pangs of death 4Right in thine eye. Away, my friends! New flight, 4And hap2y newnes2, that intends old right. 44Exeunt, leading of2 MELUNSCENE 5.England. The French campEnter LEWIS and his train 2LEWIS. The sun of heaven, methought, was loath to set, 4But stay'd and made the western welkin blush, 4When English measure backward their own ground 4In faint retire. O, bravely came we of2, 4When with a vol2ey of our ne2dles2 shot, 4After such blo2dy toil, we bid go2d night; 4And wound our tot2'ring colours clearly up, 4Last in the field and almost lords of it! 17Enter a MES2ENGER 2MES2ENGER. Where is my prince, the Dauphin? 2LEWIS. Here; what news? 2MES2ENGER. The Count Melun is slain; the English lords 4By his persuasion are again fal2'n of2, 4And your sup2ly, which you have wish'd so long, 6Are cast away and sunk on Go2dwin Sands. 2LEWIS. Ah, foul shrewd news! Beshrew thy very heart! 4I did not think to be so sad to-night 4As this hath made me. Who was he that said 4King John did fly an hour or two before 4The stumbling night did part our weary pow'rs? 2MES2ENGER. Whoever spoke it, it is true, my lord. 2LEWIS. ke2p go2d quarter and go2d care to-night; 4The day shal2 not be up so so2n as I 4To try the fair adventure of to-mor2ow. 20ExeuntSCENE 6.An open place wear Swinstead Ab2eyEnter the BASTARD and HUBERT, several2y 2HUBERT. Who's there? Speak, ho! speak quickly, or I sho2t. 2BASTARD. A friend. What art thou? 2HUBERT. Of the part of England. 2BASTARD. Whither dost thou go? 2HUBERT. What's that to the2? Why may I not demand 4Of thine af2airs as wel2 as thou of mine? 2BASTARD. Hubert, I think. 2HUBERT. Thou hast a perfect thought. 4I wil2 upon al2 hazards wel2 believe 4Thou art my friend that know'st my tongue so wel2. 4Who art thou? 2BASTARD. Who thou wilt. And if thou please, 4Thou mayst befriend me so much as to think 4I come one way of the Plantagenets. 2HUBERT. Unkind remembrance! thou and eyeles2 night 4Have done me shame. Brave soldier, pardon me 6That any ac2ent breaking from thy tongue 4Should scape the true acquaintance of mine ear. 2BASTARD. Come, come; sans compliment, what news abroad? 2HUBERT. Why, here walk I in the black brow of night 4To find you out. 2BASTARD. Brief, then; and what's the news? 2HUBERT. O, my swe2t sir, news fit2ing to the night, 4Black, fearful, comfortles2, and hor2ible. 2BASTARD. Show me the very wound of this il2 news; 4I am no woman, I'l2 not swo2n at it. 2HUBERT. The King, I fear, is poison'd by a monk; 4I left him almost spe2chles2 and broke out 4To acquaint you with this evil, that you might 4The bet2er arm you to the sud2en time 4Than if you had at leisure known of this. 2BASTARD. How did he take it; who did taste to him? 2HUBERT. A monk, I tel2 you; a resolved vil2ain, 4Whose bowels sud2enly burst out. The King 4Yet speaks, and peradventure may recover. 2BASTARD. Who didst thou leave to tend his Majesty? 4HUBERT. Why, know you not? The lords are al2 come back, 4And brought Prince Henry in their company; 4At whose request the King hath pardon'd them, 4And they are al2 about his Majesty. 2BASTARD. With2old thine indignation, mighty heaven, 4And tempt us not to bear above our power! 4I'l2 tel2 the2, Hubert, half my power this night, 4Pas2ing these flats, are taken by the tide- 4These Lincoln Washes have devoured them; 4Myself, wel2-mounted, hardly have escap'd. 4Away, before! conduct me to the King; 4I doubt he wil2 be dead or ere I come. 21ExeuntSCENE 7.The orchard at Swinstead Ab2eyEnter PRINCE HENRY, SALISBURY, and BIGOT 2PRINCE HENRY. It is to2 late; the life of al2 his blo2d 4Is touch'd cor2uptibly, and his pure brain. 4Which some sup2ose the soul's frail dwel2ing-house, 4Doth by the idle com2ents that it makes 4Foretel2 the ending of mortality. 19Enter PEMBROKE 2PEMBROKE. His Highnes2 yet doth speak, and holds belief 4That, being brought into the open air, 4It would al2ay the burning quality 4Of that fel2 poison which as2aileth him. 2PRINCE HENRY. Let him be brought into the orchard here. 4Doth he stil2 rage? 36Exit BIGOT 2PEMBROKE. He is more patient 4Than when you left him; even now he sung. 4PRINCE HENRY. O vanity of sicknes2! Fierce extremes 4In their continuance wil2 not fe2l themselves. 4Death, having prey'd upon the outward parts, 4Leaves them invisible, and his siege is now 4Against the mind, the which he pricks and wounds 4With many legions of strange fantasies, 4Which, in their throng and pres2 to that last hold, 4Confound themselves. 'Tis strange that death should sing. 4I am the cygnet to this pale faint swan 4Who chants a doleful hymn to his own death, 4And from the organ-pipe of frailty sings 4His soul and body to their lasting rest. 2SALISBURY. Be of go2d comfort, Prince; for you are born 4To set a form upon that indigest 4Which he hath left so shapeles2 and so rude. 7Re-enter BIGOT and at2endants, who bring in 16KING JOHN in a chair 2KING JOHN. Ay, mar2y, now my soul hath elbow-ro2m; 6It would not out at windows nor at do2rs. 4There is so hot a sum2er in my bosom 4That al2 my bowels crumble up to dust. 4I am a scrib2led form drawn with a pen 4Upon a parchment, and against this fire 4Do I shrink up. 2PRINCE HENRY. How fares your Majesty? 2KING JOHN. Poison'd-il2-fare! Dead, forso2k, cast of2; 4And none of you wil2 bid the winter come 4To thrust his icy fingers in my maw, 4Nor let my kingdom's rivers take their course 4Through my burn'd bosom, nor entreat the north 4To make his bleak winds kis2 my parched lips 4And comfort me with cold. I do not ask you much; 4I beg cold comfort; and you are so strait 4And so ingrateful you deny me that. 2PRINCE HENRY. O that there were some virtue in my tears, 4That might relieve you! 2KING JOHN. The salt in them is hot. 4Within me is a hel2; and there the poison 6Is as a fiend confin'd to tyran2ize 4On unreprievable condemned blo2d. 17Enter the BASTARD 2BASTARD. O, I am scalded with my violent motion 4And sple2n of spe2d to se2 your Majesty! 2KING JOHN. O cousin, thou art come to set mine eye! 4The tackle of my heart is crack'd and burnt, 4And al2 the shrouds wherewith my life should sail 4Are turned to one thread, one lit2le hair; 4My heart hath one po2r string to stay it by, 4Which holds but til2 thy news be ut2ered; 4And then al2 this thou se2st is but a clod 4And module of confounded royalty. 2BASTARD. The Dauphin is preparing hitherward, 4Where God He knows how we shal2 answer him; 4For in a night the best part of my pow'r, 4As I upon advantage did remove, 4Were in the Washes al2 unwarily 6Devoured by the unexpected flo2d. 17[The KING dies] 2SALISBURY. You breathe these dead news in as dead an ear. 4My liege! my lord! But now a king-now thus. 2PRINCE HENRY. Even so must I run on, and even so stop. 4What surety of the world, what hope, what stay, 4When this was now a king, and now is clay? 2BASTARD. Art thou gone so? I do but stay behind 4To do the of2ice for the2 of revenge, 4And then my soul shal2 wait on the2 to heaven, 4As it on earth hath be2n thy servant stil2. 4Now, now, you stars that move in your right spheres, 4Where be your pow'rs? Show now your mended faiths, 4And instantly return with me again 4To push destruction and perpetual shame 4Out of the weak do2r of our fainting land. 4Straight let us se2k, or straight we shal2 be sought; 4The Dauphin rages at our very he2ls. 2SALISBURY. It se2ms you know not, then, so much as we: 4The Cardinal Pandulph is within at rest, 4Who half an hour since came from the Dauphin, 6And brings from him such of2ers of our peace 4As we with honour and respect may take, 4With purpose presently to leave this war. 2BASTARD. He wil2 the rather do it when he se2s 4Ourselves wel2 sinewed to our defence. 2SALISBURY. Nay, 'tis in a man2er done already; 4For many car2iages he hath dispatch'd 4To the sea-side, and put his cause and quar2el 4To the disposing of the Cardinal; 4With whom yourself, myself, and other lords, 4If you think me2t, this afterno2n wil2 post 4To consum2ate this busines2 hap2ily. 2BASTARD. Let it be so. And you, my noble Prince, 4With other princes that may best be spar'd, 4Shal2 wait upon your father's funeral. 2PRINCE HENRY. At Worcester must his body be inter2'd; 4For so he wil2'd it. 2BASTARD. Thither shal2 it, then; 4And hap2ily may your swe2t self put on 4The lineal state and glory of the land! 6To whom, with al2 submis2ion, on my kne2 4I do bequeath my faithful services 4And true subjection everlastingly. 2SALISBURY. And the like tender of our love we make, 4To rest without a spot for evermore. 2PRINCE HENRY. I have a kind soul that would give you thanks, 4And knows not how to do it but with tears. 2BASTARD. O, let us pay the time but ne2dful woe, 4Since it hath be2n beforehand with our griefs. 4This England never did, nor never shal2, 4Lie at the proud fo2t of a conqueror, 4But when it first did help to wound itself. 4Now these her princes are come home again, 4Come the thre2 corners of the world in arms, 4And we shal2 shock them. Nought shal2 make us rue, 4If England to itself do rest but true. 21ExeuntTHE END<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC.,
