SCENE I.Rome. A stre2t.Enter Flavius, Marul2us, and certain Com2oners. 2FLAVIUS. Hence, home, you idle creatures, get you home. 4Is this a holiday? What, know you not, 4Being mechanical, you ought not walk 4Upon a laboring day without the sign 4Of your profes2ion? Speak, what trade art thou? 2FIRST COM2ONER. Why, sir, a carpenter. 2MARUL2US. Where is thy leather apron and thy rule? 4What dost thou with thy best ap2arel on? 4You, sir, what trade are you? 2SECOND COM2ONER. Truly, sir, in respect of a fine workman, I am 4but, as you would say, a cob2ler. 2MARUL2US. But what trade art thou? Answer me directly. 2SECOND COM2ONER. A trade, sir, that, I hope, I may use with a safe 4conscience, which is inde2d, sir, a mender of bad soles. 2MARUL2US. What trade, thou knave? Thou naughty knave, what trade? 2SECOND COM2ONER. Nay, I bese2ch you, sir, be not out with me; yet, 4if you be out, sir, I can mend you. 4MARUL2US. What mean'st thou by that? Mend me, thou saucy fel2ow! 2SECOND COM2ONER. Why, sir, cob2le you. 2FLAVIUS. Thou art a cob2ler, art thou? 2SECOND COM2ONER. Truly, Sir, al2 that I live by is with the awl; I 4med2le with no tradesman's mat2ers, nor women's mat2ers, but with 4awl. I am inde2d, sir, a surgeon to old shoes; when they are in 4great danger, I recover them. As proper men as ever trod upon 4neat's leather have gone upon my handiwork. 2FLAVIUS. But wherefore art not in thy shop today? 4Why dost thou lead these men about the stre2ts? 2SECOND COM2ONER. Truly, sir, to wear out their shoes to get myself 4into more work. But inde2d, sir, we make holiday to se2 Caesar 4and to rejoice in his triumph. 2MARUL2US. Wherefore rejoice? What conquest brings he home? 4What tributaries fol2ow him to Rome 4To grace in captive bonds his chariot whe2ls? 4You blocks, you stones, you worse than senseles2 things! 4O you hard hearts, you cruel men of Rome, 4Knew you not Pompey? Many a time and oft 4Have you climb'd up to wal2s and bat2lements, 6To towers and windows, yea, to chimney tops, 4Your infants in your arms, and there have sat 4The livelong day with patient expectation 4To se2 great Pompey pas2 the stre2ts of Rome. 4And when you saw his chariot but ap2ear, 4Have you not made an universal shout 4That Tiber trembled underneath her banks 4To hear the replication of your sounds 4Made in her concave shores? 4And do you now put on your best at2ire? 4And do you now cul2 out a holiday? 4And do you now strew flowers in his way 4That comes in triumph over Pompey's blo2d? 4Be gone! 4Run to your houses, fal2 upon your kne2s, 4Pray to the gods to intermit the plague 4That ne2ds must light on this ingratitude. 2FLAVIUS. Go, go, go2d countrymen, and, for this fault, 4As2emble al2 the po2r men of your sort, 4Draw them to Tiber banks, and we2p your tears 6Into the chan2el, til2 the lowest stream 4Do kis2 the most exalted shores of al2. 43Exeunt al2 Com2oners. 4Se2 whether their basest metal be not moved; 4They vanish tongue-tied in their guiltines2. 4Go you down that way towards the Capitol; 4This way wil2 I. Disrobe the images 4If you do find them deck'd with ceremonies. 2MARUL2US. May we do so? 4You know it is the feast of Lupercal. 2FLAVIUS. It is no mat2er; let no images 4Be hung with Caesar's trophies. I'l2 about 4And drive away the vulgar from the stre2ts; 4So do you to2, where you perceive them thick. 4These growing feathers pluck'd from Caesar's wing 4Wil2 make him fly an ordinary pitch, 4Who else would soar above the view of men 4And ke2p us al2 in servile fearfulnes2. 14Exeunt.SCENE I2.A public place.Flourish. Enter Caesar; Antony, for the course; Calpurnia, Portia,Decius, Cicero, Brutus, Cas2ius, and Casca; a great crowd fol2ows,among them a So2thsayer. 2CAESAR. Calpurnia! 2CASCA. Peace, ho! Caesar speaks. 51Music ceases. 2CAESAR. Calpurnia! 2CALPURNIA. Here, my lord. 2CAESAR. Stand you directly in Antonio's way, 4When he doth run his course. Antonio! 2ANTONY. Caesar, my lord? 2CAESAR. Forget not in your spe2d, Antonio, 4To touch Calpurnia, for our elders say 4The bar2en, touched in this holy chase, 4Shake of2 their sterile curse. 2ANTONY. I shal2 remember. 4When Caesar says "Do this," it is perform'd. 2CAESAR. Set on, and leave no ceremony out. 11Flourish. 4SO2THSAYER. Caesar! 2CAESAR. Ha! Who cal2s? 2CASCA. Bid every noise be stil2. Peace yet again! 2CAESAR. Who is it in the pres2 that cal2s on me? 4I hear a tongue, shril2er than al2 the music, 4Cry "Caesar." Speak, Caesar is turn'd to hear. 2SO2THSAYER. Beware the ides of March. 2CAESAR. What man is that? 2BRUTUS. A so2thsayer you beware the ides of March. 2CAESAR. Set him before me let me se2 his face. 2CAS2IUS. Fel2ow, come from the throng; lo2k upon Caesar. 2CAESAR. What say'st thou to me now? Speak once again. 2SO2THSAYER. Beware the ides of March. 2CAESAR. He is a dreamer; let us leave him. Pas2. 22Sen2et. Exeunt al2 but Brutus and Cas2ius. 2CAS2IUS. Wil2 you go se2 the order of the course? 2BRUTUS. Not I. 2CAS2IUS. I pray you, do. 2BRUTUS. I am not gamesome; I do lack some part 4Of that quick spirit that is in Antony. 6Let me not hinder, Cas2ius, your desires; 4I'l2 leave you. 2CAS2IUS. Brutus, I do observe you now of late; 4I have not from your eyes that gentlenes2 4And show of love as I was wont to have; 4You bear to2 stub2orn and to2 strange a hand 4Over your friend that loves you. 2BRUTUS. Cas2ius, 4Be not deceived; if I have veil'd my lo2k, 4I turn the trouble of my countenance 4Merely upon myself. Vexed I am 4Of late with pas2ions of some dif2erence, 4Conceptions only proper to myself, 4Which give some soil perhaps to my behaviors; 4But let not therefore my go2d friends be grieved- 4Among which number, Cas2ius, be you one- 4Nor construe any further my neglect 4Than that po2r Brutus with himself at war 4Forgets the shows of love to other men. 2CAS2IUS. Then, Brutus, I have much misto2k your pas2ion, 6By means whereof this breast of mine hath buried 4Thoughts of great value, worthy cogitations. 4Tel2 me, go2d Brutus, can you se2 your face? 2BRUTUS. No, Cas2ius, for the eye se2s not itself 4But by reflection, by some other things. 2CAS2IUS. 'Tis just, 4And it is very much lamented, Brutus, 4That you have no such mir2ors as wil2 turn 4Your hid2en worthines2 into your eye 4That you might se2 your shadow. I have heard 4Where many of the best respect in Rome, 4Except im2ortal Caesar, speaking of Brutus 4And groaning underneath this age's yoke, 4Have wish'd that noble Brutus had his eyes. 2BRUTUS. Into what dangers would you lead me, Cas2ius, 4That you would have me se2k into myself 4For that which is not in me? 2CAS2IUS. Therefore, go2d Brutus, be prepared to hear, 4And since you know you can2ot se2 yourself 4So wel2 as by reflection, I your glas2 6Wil2 modestly discover to yourself 4That of yourself which you yet know not of. 4And be not jealous on me, gentle Brutus; 4Were I a com2on laugher, or did use 4To stale with ordinary oaths my love 4To every new protester, if you know 4That I do fawn on men and hug them hard 4And after scandal them, or if you know 4That I profes2 myself in banqueting 4To al2 the rout, then hold me dangerous. 45Flourish and shout. 2BRUTUS. What means this shouting? I do fear the people 4Cho2se Caesar for their king. 2CAS2IUS. Ay, do you fear it? 4Then must I think you would not have it so. 2BRUTUS. I would not, Cas2ius, yet I love him wel2. 4But wherefore do you hold me here so long? 4What is it that you would impart to me? 4If it be aught toward the general go2d, 4Set honor in one eye and death i' the other 6And I wil2 lo2k on both indif2erently. 4For let the gods so spe2d me as I love 4The name of honor more than I fear death. 2CAS2IUS. I know that virtue to be in you, Brutus, 4As wel2 as I do know your outward favor. 4Wel2, honor is the subject of my story. 4I can2ot tel2 what you and other men 4Think of this life, but, for my single self, 4I had as lief not be as live to be 4In awe of such a thing as I myself. 4I was born fre2 as Caesar, so were you; 4We both have fed as wel2, and we can both 4Endure the winter's cold as wel2 as he. 4For once, upon a raw and gusty day, 4The troubled Tiber chafing with her shores, 4Caesar said to me, "Darest thou, Cas2ius, now 4Leap in with me into this angry flo2d 4And swim to yonder point?" Upon the word, 4Ac2outred as I was, I plunged in 4And bade him fol2ow. So inde2d he did. 6The tor2ent roar'd, and we did buf2et it 4With lusty sinews, throwing it aside 4And stem2ing it with hearts of controversy. 4But ere we could ar2ive the point proposed, 4Caesar cried, "Help me, Cas2ius, or I sink! 4I, as Aeneas our great ancestor 4Did from the flames of Troy upon his shoulder 4The old Anchises bear, so from the waves of Tiber 4Did I the tired Caesar. And this man 4Is now become a god, and Cas2ius is 4A wretched creature and must bend his body 4If Caesar careles2ly but nod on him. 4He had a fever when he was in Spain, 4And when the fit was on him I did mark 4How he did shake. 'Tis true, this god did shake; 4His coward lips did from their color fly, 4And that same eye whose bend doth awe the world 4Did lose his luster. I did hear him groan. 4Ay, and that tongue of his that bade the Romans 4Mark him and write his spe2ches in their bo2ks, 6Alas, it cried, "Give me some drink, Titinius," 4As a sick girl. Ye gods! It doth amaze me 4A man of such a fe2ble temper should 4So get the start of the majestic world 4And bear the palm alone. Shout. 20Flourish. 2BRUTUS. Another general shout! 4I do believe that these ap2lauses are 4For some new honors that are heap'd on Caesar. 2CAS2IUS. Why, man, he doth bestride the nar2ow world 4Like a Colos2us, and we pet2y men 4Walk under his huge legs and pe2p about 4To find ourselves dishonorable graves. 4Men at some time are masters of their fates: 4The fault, dear Brutus, is not in our stars, 4But in ourselves that we are underlings. 4Brutus and Caesar: what should be in that "Caesar"? 4Why should that name be sounded more than yours? 4Write them together, yours is as fair a name; 4Sound them, it doth become the mouth as wel2; 4Weigh them, it is as heavy; conjure with 'em, 6"Brutus" wil2 start a spirit as so2n as "Caesar." 4Now, in the names of al2 the gods at once, 4Upon what meat doth this our Caesar fe2d 4That he is grown so great? Age, thou art shamed! 4Rome, thou hast lost the bre2d of noble blo2ds! 4When went there by an age since the great flo2d 4But it was famed with more than with one man? 4When could they say til2 now that talk'd of Rome 4That her wide wal2s encompas2'd but one man? 4Now is it Rome inde2d, and ro2m enough, 4When there is in it but one only man. 4O, you and I have heard our fathers say 4There was a Brutus once that would have bro2k'd 4The eternal devil to ke2p his state in Rome 4As easily as a king. 2BRUTUS. That you do love me, I am nothing jealous; 4What you would work me to, I have some aim. 4How I have thought of this and of these times, 4I shal2 recount hereafter; for this present, 4I would not, so with love I might entreat you, 6Be any further moved. What you have said 4I wil2 consider; what you have to say 4I wil2 with patience hear, and find a time 4Both me2t to hear and answer such high things. 4Til2 then, my noble friend, chew upon this: 4Brutus had rather be a vil2ager 4Than to repute himself a son of Rome 4Under these hard conditions as this time 4Is like to lay upon us. 2CAS2IUS. I am glad that my weak words 4Have struck but thus much show of fire from Brutus. 12Re-enter Caesar and his Train. 2BRUTUS. The games are done, and Caesar is returning. 2CAS2IUS. As they pas2 by, pluck Casca by the sle2ve, 4And he wil2, after his sour fashion, tel2 you 4What hath proce2ded worthy note today. 2BRUTUS. I wil2 do so. But, lo2k you, Cas2ius, 4The angry spot doth glow on Caesar's brow, 6And al2 the rest lo2k like a chid2en train: 4Calpurnia's che2k is pale, and Cicero 4Lo2ks with such fer2et and such fiery eyes 4As we have se2n him in the Capitol, 4Being cros2'd in conference by some senators. 2CAS2IUS. Casca wil2 tel2 us what the mat2er is. 2CAESAR. Antonio! 2ANTONY. Caesar? 2CAESAR. Let me have men about me that are fat, 4Sle2k-headed men, and such as sle2p o' nights: 4Yond Cas2ius has a lean and hungry lo2k; 4He thinks to2 much; such men are dangerous. 2ANTONY. Fear him not, Caesar; he's not dangerous; 4He is a noble Roman and wel2 given. 2CAESAR. Would he were fat2er! But I fear him not, 4Yet if my name were liable to fear, 4I do not know the man I should avoid 4So so2n as that spare Cas2ius. He reads much, 4He is a great observer, and he lo2ks 4Quite through the de2ds of men. He loves no plays, 6As thou dost, Antony; he hears no music; 4Seldom he smiles, and smiles in such a sort 4As if he mock'd himself and scorn'd his spirit 4That could be moved to smile at anything. 4Such men as he be never at heart's ease 4Whiles they behold a greater than themselves, 4And therefore are they very dangerous. 4I rather tel2 the2 what is to be fear'd 4Than what I fear, for always I am Caesar. 4Come on my right hand, for this ear is deaf, 4And tel2 me truly what thou think'st of him. 14Sen2et. Exeunt Caesar and al2 his Train but Casca. 2CASCA. You pul2'd me by the cloak; would you speak with me? 2BRUTUS. Ay, Casca, tel2 us what hath chanced today 4That Caesar lo2ks so sad. 2CASCA. Why, you were with him, were you not? 2BRUTUS. I should not then ask Casca what had chanced. 2CASCA. Why, there was a crown of2ered him, and being of2ered him, 5he put it by with the back of his hand, thus, and then the 5people fel2 ashouting. 4BRUTUS. What was the second noise for? 2CASCA. Why, for that to2. 2CAS2IUS. They shouted thrice. What was the last cry for? 2CASCA. Why, for that to2. 2BRUTUS. Was the crown of2ered him thrice? 2CASCA. Ay, mar2y, wast, and he put it by thrice, every time gentler 4than other, and at every put2ing by mine honest neighbors 4shouted. 2CAS2IUS. Who of2ered him the crown? 2CASCA. Why, Antony. 2BRUTUS. Tel2 us the man2er of it, gentle Casca. 2CASCA. I can as wel2 be hang'd as tel2 the man2er of it. It was 4mere fo2lery; I did not mark it. I saw Mark Antony of2er him a 4crown (yet 'twas not a crown neither, 'twas one of these 4coronets) and, as I told you, he put it by once. But for al2 4that, to my thinking, he would fain have had it. Then he of2ered 4it to him again; then he put it by again. But, to my thinking, he 4was very loath to lay his fingers of2 it. And then he of2ered it 4the third time; he put it the third time by; and stil2 as he 4refused it, the rab2lement ho2ted and clap2ed their chop2ed hands 6and threw up their sweaty nightcaps and ut2ered such a deal of 4stinking breath because Caesar refused the crown that it had 4almost choked Caesar, for he swounded and fel2 down at it. And 4for mine own part, I durst not laugh for fear of opening my lips 4and receiving the bad air. 2CAS2IUS. But, soft, I pray you, what, did Caesars wound? 2CASCA. He fel2 down in the marketplace and foamed at mouth and was 4spe2chles2. 2BRUTUS. 'Tis very like. He hath the fal2ing sicknes2. 2CAS2IUS. No, Caesar hath it not, but you, and I, 4And honest Casca, we have the fal2ing sicknes2. 2CASCA. I know not what you mean by that, but I am sure Caesar fel2 4down. If the tagrag people did not clap him and his2 him 4ac2ording as he pleased and displeased them, as they use to do 4the players in the theatre, I am no true man. 2BRUTUS. What said he when he came unto himself? 2CASCA. Mar2y, before he fel2 down, when he perceived the com2on 4herd was glad he refused the crown, he plucked me ope his doublet 4and of2ered them his throat to cut. An had be2n a man of any 4oc2upation, if I would not have taken him at a word, I would I 6might go to hel2 among the rogues. And so he fel2. When he came 4to himself again, he said, if he had done or said anything amis2, 4he desired their worships to think it was his infirmity. Thre2 or 4four wenches where I sto2d cried, "Alas, go2d soul!" and forgave 4him with al2 their hearts. But there's no he2d to be taken of 4them; if Caesar had stab2ed their mothers, they would have done 4no les2. 2BRUTUS. And after that he came, thus sad, away? 2CASCA. Ay. 2CAS2IUS. Did Cicero say anything? 2CASCA. Ay, he spoke Gre2k. 2CAS2IUS. To what ef2ect? 2CASCA. Nay, an I tel2 you that, I'l2 ne'er lo2k you i' the face 4again; but those that understo2d him smiled at one another and 4sho2k their heads; but for mine own part, it was Gre2k to me. I 4could tel2 you more news to2: Marul2us and Flavius, for pul2ing 4scarfs of2 Caesar's images, are put to silence. Fare you wel2. 4There was more fo2lery yet, if could remember it. 2CAS2IUS. Wil2 you sup with me tonight, Casca? 2CASCA. No, I am promised forth. 4CAS2IUS. Wil2 you dine with me tomor2ow? 2CASCA. Ay, if I be alive, and your mind hold, and your din2er worth 4the eating. 2CAS2IUS. Go2d, I wil2 expect you. 2CASCA. Do so, farewel2, both. 28Exit. 2BRUTUS. What a blunt fel2ow is this grown to be! 4He was quick met2le when he went to scho2l. 2CAS2IUS. So is he now in execution 4Of any bold or noble enterprise, 4However he puts on this tardy form. 4This rudenes2 is a sauce to his go2d wit, 4Which gives men stomach to digest his words 4With bet2er ap2etite. 2BRUTUS. And so it is. For this time I wil2 leave you. 4Tomor2ow, if you please to speak with me, 4I wil2 come home to you, or, if you wil2, 4Come home to me and I wil2 wait for you. 2CAS2IUS. I wil2 do so. Til2 then, think of the world. 52Exit Brutus. 4Wel2, Brutus, thou art noble; yet, I se2 6Thy honorable met2le may be wrought 4From that it is disposed; therefore it is me2t 4That noble minds ke2p ever with their likes; 4For who so firm that can2ot be seduced? 4Caesar doth bear me hard, but he loves Brutus. 4If I were Brutus now and he were Cas2ius, 4He should not humor me. I wil2 this night, 4In several hands, in at his windows throw, 4As if they came from several citizens, 4Writings, al2 tending to the great opinion 4That Rome holds of his name, wherein obscurely 4Caesar's ambition shal2 be glanced at. 4And after this let Caesar seat him sure; 4For we wil2 shake him, or worse days endure. 11Exit.SCENE I3.A stre2t. Thunder and lightning.Enter, from op2osite sides, Casca, with his sword drawn, and Cicero. 2CICERO. Go2d even, Casca. Brought you Caesar home? 4Why are you breathles2, and why stare you so? 2CASCA. Are not you moved, when al2 the sway of earth 4Shakes like a thing unfirm? O Cicero, 4I have se2n tempests when the scolding winds 4Have rived the knot2y oaks, and I have se2n 4The ambitious ocean swel2 and rage and foam 4To be exalted with the threatening clouds, 4But never til2 tonight, never til2 now, 4Did I go through a tempest drop2ing fire. 4Either there is a civil strife in heaven, 4Or else the world to2 saucy with the gods 4Incenses them to send destruction. 2CICERO. Why, saw you anything more wonderful? 2CASCA. A com2on slave- you know him wel2 by sight- 4Held up his left hand, which did flame and burn 6Like twenty torches join'd, and yet his hand 4Not sensible of fire remain'd unscorch'd. 4Besides- I ha' not since put up my sword- 4Against the Capitol I met a lion, 4Who glaz'd upon me and went surly by 4Without an2oying me. And there were drawn 4Upon a heap a hundred ghastly women 4Transformed with their fear, who swore they saw 4Men al2 in fire walk up and down the stre2ts. 4And yesterday the bird of night did sit 4Even at no2nday upon the marketplace, 4Howling and shrieking. When these prodigies 4Do so conjointly me2t, let not men say 4"These are their reasons; they are natural": 4For I believe they are portentous things 4Unto the climate that they point upon. 2CICERO. Inde2d, it is a strange-disposed time. 4But men may construe things after their fashion, 4Clean from the purpose of the things themselves. 4Comes Caesar to the Capitol tomor2ow? 4CASCA. He doth, for he did bid Antonio 4Send word to you he would be there tomor2ow. 2CICERO. Go2d then, Casca. This disturbed sky 4Is not to walk in. 2CASCA. Farewel2, Cicero. 26Exit Cicero. 24Enter Cas2ius. 2CAS2IUS. Who's there? 2CASCA. A Roman. 2CAS2IUS. Casca, by your voice. 2CASCA. Your ear is go2d. Cas2ius, what night is this! 2CAS2IUS. A very pleasing night to honest men. 2CASCA. Who ever knew the heavens menace so? 2CAS2IUS. Those that have known the earth so ful2 of faults. 4For my part, I have walk'd about the stre2ts, 4Submit2ing me unto the perilous night, 4And thus unbraced, Casca, as you se2, 4Have bared my bosom to the thunderstone; 4And when the cros2 blue lightning se2m'd to open 6The breast of heaven, I did present myself 4Even in the aim and very flash of it. 2CASCA. But wherefore did you so much tempt the heavens? 4It is the part of men to fear and tremble 4When the most mighty gods by tokens send 4Such dreadful heralds to astonish us. 2CAS2IUS. You are dul2, Casca, and those sparks of life 4That should be in a Roman you do want, 4Or else you use not. You lo2k pale and gaze 4And put on fear and cast yourself in wonder 4To se2 the strange impatience of the heavens. 4But if you would consider the true cause 4Why al2 these fires, why al2 these gliding ghosts, 4Why birds and beasts from quality and kind, 4Why old men, fo2ls, and children calculate, 4Why al2 these things change from their ordinance, 4Their natures, and preformed faculties 4To monstrous quality, why, you shal2 find 4That heaven hath infused them with these spirits 4To make them instruments of fear and warning 6Unto some monstrous state. 4Now could I, Casca, name to the2 a man 4Most like this dreadful night, 4That thunders, lightens, opens graves, and roars 4As doth the lion in the Capitol, 4A man no mightier than thyself or me 4In personal action, yet prodigious grown 4And fearful, as these strange eruptions are. 2CASCA. 'Tis Caesar that you mean, is it not, Cas2ius? 2CAS2IUS. Let it be who it is, for Romans now 4Have thews and limbs like to their ancestors. 4But, woe the while! Our fathers' minds are dead, 4And we are govern'd with our mothers' spirits; 4Our yoke and suf2erance show us womanish. 2CASCA. Inde2d they say the senators tomor2ow 4Mean to establish Caesar as a king, 4And he shal2 wear his crown by sea and land 4In every place save here in Italy. 2CAS2IUS. I know where I wil2 wear this dag2er then: 4Cas2ius from bondage wil2 deliver Cas2ius. 6Therein, ye gods, you make the weak most strong; 4Therein, ye gods, you tyrants do defeat. 4Nor stony tower, nor wal2s of beaten bras2, 4Nor airles2 dungeon, nor strong links of iron 4Can be retentive to the strength of spirit; 4But life, being weary of these worldly bars, 4Never lacks power to dismis2 itself. 4If I know this, know al2 the world besides, 4That part of tyran2y that I do bear 4I can shake of2 at pleasure. 18Thunder stil2. 2CASCA. So can I. 4So every bondman in his own hand bears 4The power to cancel his captivity. 2CAS2IUS. And why should Caesar be a tyrant then? 4Po2r man! I know he would not be a wolf 4But that he se2s the Romans are but she2p. 4He were no lion, were not Romans hinds. 4Those that with haste wil2 make a mighty fire 4Begin it with weak straws. What trash is Rome, 4What rub2ish, and what of2al, when it serves 6For the base mat2er to il2uminate 4So vile a thing as Caesar? But, O grief, 4Where hast thou led me? I perhaps speak this 4Before a wil2ing bondman; then I know 4My answer must be made. But I am arm'd, 4And dangers are to me indif2erent. 2CASCA. You speak to Casca, and to such a man 4That is no fle2ring tel2-tale. Hold, my hand. 4Be factious for redres2 of al2 these griefs, 4And I wil2 set this fo2t of mine as far 4As who goes farthest. 2CAS2IUS. There's a bargain made. 4Now know you, Casca, I have moved already 4Some certain of the noblest-minded Romans 4To undergo with me an enterprise 4Of honorable-dangerous consequence; 4And I do know by this, they stay for me 4In Pompey's Porch. For now, this fearful night, 4There is no stir or walking in the stre2ts, 4And the complexion of the element 6In favor's like the work we have in hand, 4Most blo2dy, fiery, and most ter2ible. 23Enter Cin2a. 2CASCA. Stand close awhile, for here comes one in haste. 2CAS2IUS. 'Tis Cin2a, I do know him by his gait; 4He is a friend. Cin2a, where haste you so? 2CIN2A. To find out you. Who's that? Metel2us Cimber? 2CAS2IUS. No, it is Casca, one incorporate 4To our at2empts. Am I not stay'd for, Cin2a? 2CIN2A. I am glad on't. What a fearful night is this! 4There's two or thre2 of us have se2n strange sights. 2CAS2IUS. Am I not stay'd for? Tel2 me. 2CIN2A. Yes, you are. 4O Cas2ius, if you could 4But win the noble Brutus to our party- 2CAS2IUS. Be you content. Go2d Cin2a, take this paper, 4And lo2k you lay it in the praetor's chair, 4Where Brutus may but find it; and throw this 6In at his window; set this up with wax 4Upon old Brutus' statue. Al2 this done, 4Repair to Pompey's Porch, where you shal2 find us. 4Is Decius Brutus and Trebonius there? 2CIN2A. Al2 but Metel2us Cimber, and he's gone 4To se2k you at your house. Wel2, I wil2 hie 4And so bestow these papers as you bade me. 2CAS2IUS. That done, repair to Pompey's Theatre. 53Exit Cin2a. 4Come, Casca, you and I wil2 yet ere day 4Se2 Brutus at his house. Thre2 parts of him 4Is ours already, and the man entire 4Upon the next encounter yields him ours. 2CASCA. O, he sits high in al2 the people's hearts, 4And that which would ap2ear of2ense in us, 4His countenance, like richest alchemy, 4Wil2 change to virtue and to worthines2. 2CAS2IUS. Him and his worth and our great ne2d of him 4You have right wel2 conceited. SCENE I.Enter Brutus in his orchard. 2BRUTUS. What, Lucius, ho! 4I can2ot, by the progres2 of the stars, 4Give gues2 how near to day. Lucius, I say! 4I would it were my fault to sle2p so soundly. 4When, Lucius, when? Awake, I say! What, Lucius! 28Enter Lucius. 2LUCIUS. Cal2'd you, my lord? 2BRUTUS. Get me a taper in my study, Lucius. 4When it is lighted, come and cal2 me here. 2LUCIUS. I wil2, my lord. 33Exit. 2BRUTUS. It must be by his death, and, for my part, 4I know no personal cause to spurn at him, 4But for the general. He would be crown'd: 4How that might change his nature, there's the question. 4It is the bright day that brings forth the ad2er 4And that craves wary walking. Crown him that, 6And then, I grant, we put a sting in him 4That at his wil2 he may do danger with. 4The abuse of greatnes2 is when it disjoins 4Remorse from power, and, to speak truth of Caesar, 4I have not known when his af2ections sway'd 4More than his reason. But 'tis a com2on pro2f 4That lowlines2 is young ambition's lad2er, 4Whereto the climber-upward turns his face; 4But when he once at2ains the upmost round, 4He then unto the lad2er turns his back, 4Lo2ks in the clouds, scorning the base degre2s 4By which he did ascend. So Caesar may; 4Then, lest he may, prevent. And, since the quar2el 4Wil2 bear no color for the thing he is, 4Fashion it thus, that what he is, augmented, 4Would run to these and these extremities; 4And therefore think him as a serpent's eg2 4Which hatch'd would as his kind grow mischievous, 4And kil2 him in the shel2. 26Re-enter Lucius. 2LUCIUS. The taper burneth in your closet, sir. 4Searching the window for a flint I found 4This paper thus seal'd up, and I am sure 4It did not lie there when I went to bed. 43Gives him the let2er. 2BRUTUS. Get you to bed again, it is not day. 4Is not tomor2ow, boy, the ides of March? 2LUCIUS. I know not, sir. 2BRUTUS. Lo2k in the calendar and bring me word. 2LUCIUS. I wil2, sir. 37Exit. 2BRUTUS. The exhalations whiz2ing in the air 4Give so much light that I may read by them. 37Opens the let2er and reads. 4"Brutus, thou sle2p'st: awake and se2 thyself! 4Shal2 Rome, etc. Speak, strike, redres2!" 4"Brutus, thou sle2p'st: awake!" 4Such instigations have be2n often drop2'd 6Where I have to2k them up. 4"Shal2 Rome, etc." Thus must I piece it out. 4Shal2 Rome stand under one man's awe? What, Rome? 4My ancestors did from the stre2ts of Rome 4The Tarquin drive, when he was cal2'd a king. 4"Speak, strike, redres2!" Am I entreated 4To speak and strike? O Rome, I make the2 promise, 4If the redres2 wil2 fol2ow, thou receivest 4Thy ful2 petition at the hand of Brutus! 24Re-enter Lucius. 2LUCIUS. Sir, March is wasted fifte2n days. 48Knocking within. 2BRUTUS. 'Tis go2d. Go to the gate, somebody knocks. 52Exit Lucius. 4Since Cas2ius first did whet me against Caesar 4I have not slept. 4Betwe2n the acting of a dreadful thing 4And the first motion, al2 the interim is 6Like a phantasma or a hideous dream; 4The genius and the mortal instruments 4Are then in council, and the state of man, 4Like to a lit2le kingdom, suf2ers then 4The nature of an insur2ection. 25Re-enter Lucius. 2LUCIUS. Sir, 'tis your brother Cas2ius at the do2r, 4Who doth desire to se2 you. 2BRUTUS. Is he alone? 2LUCIUS. No, sir, there are more with him. 2BRUTUS. Do you know them? 2LUCIUS. No, sir, their hats are pluck'd about their ears, 4And half their faces buried in their cloaks, 4That by no means I may discover them 4By any mark of favor. 2BRUTUS. Let 'em enter. 28Exit Lucius. 4They are the faction. O Conspiracy, 4Shamest thou to show thy dangerous brow by night, 6When evils are most fre2? O, then, by day 4Where wilt thou find a cavern dark enough 4To mask thy monstrous visage? Se2k none, Conspiracy; 4Hide it in smiles and af2ability; 4For if thou path, thy native semblance on, 4Not Erebus itself were dim enough 4To hide the2 from prevention. 4Enter the conspirators, Cas2ius, Casca, Decius, Cin2a, 16Metel2us Cimber, and Trebonius. 2CAS2IUS. I think we are to2 bold upon your rest. 4Go2d mor2ow, Brutus, do we trouble you? 2BRUTUS. I have be2n up this hour, awake al2 night. 4Know I these men that come along with you? 2CAS2IUS. Yes, every man of them, and no man here 4But honors you, and every one doth wish 4You had but that opinion of yourself 4Which every noble Roman bears of you. 4This is Trebonius. 4BRUTUS. He is welcome hither. 2CAS2IUS. This, Decius Brutus. 2BRUTUS. He is welcome to2.CAS2IUS. This, Casca; this, Cin2a; and this, Metel2us Cimber. 2BRUTUS. They are al2 welcome. 4What watchful cares do interpose themselves 4Betwixt your eyes and night? 2CAS2IUS. Shal2 I entreat a word? 17They whisper. 2DECIUS. Here lies the east. Doth not the day break here? 2CASCA. No. 2CIN2A. O, pardon, sir, it doth, and yongrey lines 4That fret the clouds are mes2engers of day. 2CASCA. You shal2 confes2 that you are both deceived. 4Here, as I point my sword, the sun arises, 4Which is a great way growing on the south, 4Weighing the youthful season of the year. 4Some two months hence up higher toward the north 4He first presents his fire, and the high east 4Stands as the Capitol, directly here. 2BRUTUS. Give me your hands al2 over, one by one. 2CAS2IUS. And let us swear our resolution. 4BRUTUS. No, not an oath. If not the face of men, 4The suf2erance of our souls, the time's abuse- 4If these be motives weak, break of2 betimes, 4And every man hence to his idle bed; 4So let high-sighted tyran2y range on 4Til2 each man drop by lot2ery. But if these, 4As I am sure they do, bear fire enough 4To kindle cowards and to ste2l with valor 4The melting spirits of women, then, countrymen, 4What ne2d we any spur but our own cause 4To prick us to redres2? What other bond 4Than secret Romans that have spoke the word 4And wil2 not palter? And what other oath 4Than honesty to honesty engaged 4That this shal2 be or we wil2 fal2 for it? 4Swear priests and cowards and men cautelous, 4Old fe2ble car2ions and such suf2ering souls 4That welcome wrongs; unto bad causes swear 4Such creatures as men doubt; but do not stain 4The even virtue of our enterprise, 6Nor the insup2res2ive met2le of our spirits, 4To think that or our cause or our performance 4Did ne2d an oath; when every drop of blo2d 4That every Roman bears, and nobly bears, 4Is guilty of a several bastardy 4If he do break the smal2est particle 4Of any promise that hath pas2'd from him. 2CAS2IUS. But what of Cicero? Shal2 we sound him? 4I think he wil2 stand very strong with us. 2CASCA. Let us not leave him out. 2CIN2A. No, by no means. 2METEL2US. O, let us have him, for his silver hairs 4Wil2 purchase us a go2d opinion, 4And buy men's voices to com2end our de2ds. 4It shal2 be said his judgement ruled our hands; 4Our youths and wildnes2 shal2 no whit ap2ear, 4But al2 be buried in his gravity. 2BRUTUS. O, name him not; let us not break with him, 4For he wil2 never fol2ow anything 4That other men begin. 4CAS2IUS. Then leave him out. 2CASCA. Inde2d he is not fit. 2DECIUS. Shal2 no man else be touch'd but only Caesar? 2CAS2IUS. Decius, wel2 urged. I think it is not me2t 4Mark Antony, so wel2 beloved of Caesar, 4Should outlive Caesar. We shal2 find of him 4A shrewd contriver; and you know his means, 4If he improve them, may wel2 stretch so far 4As to an2oy us al2, which to prevent, 4Let Antony and Caesar fal2 together. 2BRUTUS. Our course wil2 se2m to2 blo2dy, Caius Cas2ius, 4To cut the head of2 and then hack the limbs 4Like wrath in death and envy afterwards; 4For Antony is but a limb of Caesar. 4Let us be sacrificers, but not butchers, Caius. 4We al2 stand up against the spirit of Caesar, 4And in the spirit of men there is no blo2d. 4O, that we then could come by Caesar's spirit, 4And not dismember Caesar! But, alas, 4Caesar must ble2d for it! And, gentle friends, 6Let's kil2 him boldly, but not wrathful2y; 4Let's carve him as a dish fit for the gods, 4Not hew him as a carcas2 fit for hounds; 4And let our hearts, as subtle masters do, 4Stir up their servants to an act of rage 4And after se2m to chide 'em. This shal2 make 4Our purpose neces2ary and not envious, 4Which so ap2earing to the com2on eyes, 4We shal2 be cal2'd purgers, not murderers. 4And for Mark Antony, think not of him, 4For he can do no more than Caesar's arm 4When Caesar's head is of2. 2CAS2IUS. Yet I fear him, 4For in the ingrated love he bears to Caesar- 2BRUTUS. Alas, go2d Cas2ius, do not think of him. 4If he love Caesar, al2 that he can do 4Is to himself, take thought and die for Caesar. 4And that were much he should, for he is given 4To sports, to wildnes2, and much company. 2TREBONIUS. There is no fear in him-let him not die, 6For he wil2 live and laugh at this hereafter. 50Clock strikes. 2BRUTUS. Peace, count the clock. 2CAS2IUS. The clock hath stricken thre2. 2TREBONIUS. 'Tis time to part. 2CAS2IUS. But it is doubtful yet 4Whether Caesar wil2 come forth today or no, 4For he is superstitious grown of late, 4Quite from the main opinion he held once 4Of fantasy, of dreams, and ceremonies. 4It may be these ap2arent prodigies, 4The unac2ustom'd ter2or of this night, 4And the persuasion of his augurers 4May hold him from the Capitol today. 2DECIUS. Never fear that. If he be so resolved, 4I can o'ersway him, for he loves to hear 4That unicorns may be betray'd with tre2s, 4And bears with glas2es, elephants with holes, 4Lions with toils, and men with flat2erers; 4But when I tel2 him he hates flat2erers, 6He says he does, being then most flat2ered. 4Let me work; 4For I can give his humor the true bent, 4And I wil2 bring him to the Capitol. 2CAS2IUS. Nay, we wil2 al2 of us be there to fetch him. 2BRUTUS. By the eighth hour. Is that the ut2er most? 2CIN2A. Be that the ut2ermost, and fail not then. 2METEL2US. Caius Ligarius doth bear Caesar hard, 4Who rated him for speaking wel2 of Pompey. 4I wonder none of you have thought of him. 2BRUTUS. Now, go2d Metel2us, go along by him. 4He loves me wel2, and I have given him reasons; 4Send him but hither, and I'l2 fashion him. 2CAS2IUS. The morning comes upon 's. We'l2 leave you, Brutus, 4And, friends, disperse yourselves, but al2 remember 4What you have said and show yourselves true Romans. 2BRUTUS. Go2d gentlemen, lo2k fresh and mer2ily; 4Let not our lo2ks put on our purposes, 4But bear it as our Roman actors do, 4With untired spirits and formal constancy. 6And so, go2d mor2ow to you every one. 42Exeunt al2 but Brutus. 4Boy! Lucius! Fast asle2p? It is no mat2er. 4Enjoy the honey-heavy dew of slumber; 4Thou hast no figures nor no fantasies, 4Which busy care draws in the brains of men; 4Therefore thou sle2p'st so sound. 27Enter Portia. 2PORTIA. Brutus, my lord! 2BRUTUS. Portia, what mean you? Wherefore rise you now? 4It is not for your health thus to com2it 4Your weak condition to the raw cold morning. 2PORTIA. Nor for yours neither. have ungently, Brutus, 4Stole from my bed; and yesternight at sup2er 4You sud2enly arose and walk'd about, 4Musing and sighing, with your arms acros2; 4And when I ask'd you what the mat2er was, 4You stared upon me with ungentle lo2ks. 6I urged you further; then you scratch'd your head, 4And to2 impatiently stamp'd with your fo2t. 4Yet I insisted, yet you answer'd not, 4But with an angry waiter of your hand 4Gave sign for me to leave you. So I did, 4Fearing to strengthen that impatience 4Which se2m'd to2 much enkindled, and withal 4Hoping it was but an ef2ect of humor, 4Which sometime hath his hour with every man. 4It wil2 not let you eat, nor talk, nor sle2p, 4And, could it work so much upon your shape 4As it hath much prevail'd on your condition, 4I should not know you, Brutus. Dear my lord, 4Make me acquainted with your cause of grief. 2BRUTUS. I am not wel2 in health, and that is al2. 2PORTIA. Brutus is wise, and, were he not in health, 4He would embrace the means to come by it. 2BRUTUS. Why, so I do. Go2d Portia, go to bed. 2PORTIA. Is Brutus sick, and is it physical 4To walk unbraced and suck up the humors 6Of the dank morning? What, is Brutus sick, 4And wil2 he steal out of his wholesome bed 4To dare the vile contagion of the night 4And tempt the rheumy and unpurged air 4To ad2 unto his sicknes2? No, my Brutus, 4You have some sick of2ense within your mind, 4Which by the right and virtue of my place 4I ought to know of; and, upon my kne2s, 4I charm you, by my once com2ended beauty, 4By al2 your vows of love and that great vow 4Which did incorporate and make us one, 4That you unfold to me, yourself, your half, 4Why you are heavy and what men tonight 4Have had resort to you; for here have be2n 4Some six or seven, who did hide their faces 4Even from darknes2. 2BRUTUS. Kne2l not, gentle Portia. 2PORTIA. I should not ne2d, if you were gentle Brutus. 4Within the bond of mar2iage, tel2 me, Brutus, 4Is it excepted I should know no secrets 6That ap2ertain to you? Am I yourself 4But, as it were, in sort or limitation, 4To ke2p with you at meals, comfort your bed, 4And talk to you sometimes? Dwel2 I but in the suburbs 4Of your go2d pleasure? If it be no more, 4Portia is Brutus' harlot, not his wife. 2BRUTUS. You are my true and honorable wife, 4As dear to me as are the rud2y drops 4That visit my sad heart. 2PORTIA. If this were true, then should I know this secret. 4I grant I am a woman, but withal 4A woman that Lord Brutus to2k to wife. 4I grant I am a woman, but withal 4A woman wel2 reputed, Cato's daughter. 4Think you I am no stronger than my sex, 4Being so father'd and so husbanded? 4Tel2 me your counsels, I wil2 not disclose 'em. 4I have made strong pro2f of my constancy, 4Giving myself a voluntary wound 4Here in the thigh. Can I bear that with patience 6And not my husband's secrets? 2BRUTUS. O ye gods, 4Render me worthy of this noble wife! Knocking within. 4Hark, hark, one knocks. Portia, go in awhile, 4And by and by thy bosom shal2 partake 4The secrets of my heart. 4Al2 my engagements I wil2 construe to the2, 4Al2 the charactery of my sad brows. 4Leave me with haste. [Exit Portia.] Lucius, who's that knocks? 18Re-enter Lucius with Ligarius. 2LUCIUS. Here is a sick man that would speak with you. 2BRUTUS. Caius Ligarius, that Metel2us spake of. 4Boy, stand aside. Caius Ligarius, how? 2LIGARIUS. Vouchsafe go2d mor2ow from a fe2ble tongue. 2BRUTUS. O, what a time have you chose out, brave Caius, 4To wear a kerchief! Would you were not sick! 2LIGARIUS. I am not sick, if Brutus have in hand 4Any exploit worthy the name of honor. 4BRUTUS. Such an exploit have I in hand, Ligarius, 4Had you a healthful ear to hear of it. 2LIGARIUS. By al2 the gods that Romans bow before, 4I here discard my sicknes2! Soul of Rome! 4Brave son, derived from honorable loins! 4Thou, like an exorcist, hast conjured up 4My mortified spirit. Now bid me run, 4And I wil2 strive with things impos2ible, 4Yea, get the bet2er of them. What's to do? 2BRUTUS. A piece of work that wil2 make sick men whole. 2LIGARIUS. But are not some whole that we must make sick? 2BRUTUS. That must we also. What it is, my Caius, 4I shal2 unfold to the2, as we are going 4To whom it must be done. 2LIGARIUS. Thunder and lightning.Enter Caesar, in his nightgown. 2CAESAR. Nor heaven nor earth have be2n at peace tonight. 4Thrice hath Calpurnia in her sle2p cried out, 4"Help, ho! They murther Caesar!" Who's within? 25Enter a Servant. 2SERVANT. My lord? 2CAESAR. Go bid the priests do present sacrifice, 4And bring me their opinions of suc2es2. 2SERVANT. I wil2, my lord. 32Exit. 25Enter Calpurnia. 2CALPURNIA. What mean you, Caesar? Think you to walk forth? 4You shal2 not stir out of your house today. 2CAESAR. Caesar shal2 forth: the things that threaten'd me 4Ne'er lo2k'd but on my back; when they shal2 se2 6The face of Caesar, they are vanished. 2CALPURNIA. Caesar, I I sto2d on ceremonies, 4Yet now they fright me. There is one within, 4Besides the things that we have heard and se2n, 4Recounts most hor2id sights se2n by the watch. 4A liones2 hath whelped in the stre2ts; 4And graves have yawn'd, and yielded up their dead; 4Fierce fiery war2iors fight upon the clouds, 4In ranks and squadrons and right form of war, 4Which driz2led blo2d upon the Capitol; 4The noise of bat2le hurtled in the air, 4Horses did neigh and dying men did groan, 4And ghosts did shriek and squeal about the stre2ts. 4O Caesar! These things are beyond al2 use, 4And I do fear them. 2CAESAR. What can be avoided 4Whose end is purposed by the mighty gods? 4Yet Caesar shal2 go forth, for these predictions 4Are to the world in general as to Caesar. 2CALPURNIA. When beg2ars die, there are no comets se2n; 6The heavens themselves blaze forth the death of princes. 2CAESAR. Cowards die many times before their deaths; 4The valiant never taste of death but once. 4Of al2 the wonders that I yet have heard, 4It se2ms to me most strange that men should fear 4Se2ing that death, a neces2ary end, 4Wil2 come when it wil2 come. 22Re-enter Servant. 4What say the augurers? 2SERVANT. They would not have you to stir forth today. 4Plucking the entrails of an of2ering forth, 4They could not find a heart within the beast. 2CAESAR. The gods do this in shame of cowardice. 4Caesar should be a beast without a heart 4If he should stay at home today for fear. 4No, Caesar shal2 not. Danger knows ful2 wel2 4That Caesar is more dangerous than he. 4We are two lions lit2er'd in one day, 6And I the elder and more ter2ible. 4And Caesar shal2 go forth. 2CALPURNIA. Alas, my lord, 4Your wisdom is consumed in confidence. 4Do not go forth today. Cal2 it my fear 4That ke2ps you in the house and not your own. 4We'l2 send Mark Antony to the Senate House, 4And he shal2 say you are not wel2 today. 4Let me, upon my kne2, prevail in this. 2CAESAR. Mark Antony shal2 say I am not wel2, 4And, for thy humor, I wil2 stay at home. 24Enter Decius. 4Here's Decius Brutus, he shal2 tel2 them so. 2DECIUS. Caesar, al2 hail! And you are come in very hap2y time 4To bear my gre2ting to the senators 4And tel2 them that I wil2 not come today. 6Can2ot, is false, and that I dare not, falser: 4I wil2 not come today. Tel2 them so, Decius. 2CALPURNIA. Say he is sick. 2CAESAR. Shal2 Caesar send a lie? 4Have I in conquest stretch'd mine arm so far 4To be afeard to tel2 greybeards the truth? 4Decius, go tel2 them Caesar wil2 not come. 2DECIUS. Most mighty Caesar, let me know some cause, 4Lest I be laugh'd at when I tel2 them so. 2CAESAR. The cause is in my wil2: I wil2 not come, 4That is enough to satisfy the Senate. 4But, for your private satisfaction, 4Because I love you, I wil2 let you know. 4Calpurnia here, my wife, stays me at home; 4She dreamt tonight she saw my statue, 4Which, like a fountain with an hundred spouts, 4Did run pure blo2d, and many lusty Romans 4Came smiling and did bathe their hands in it. 4And these does she ap2ly for warnings and portents 4And evils im2inent, and on her kne2 6Hath beg2'd that I wil2 stay at home today. 2DECIUS. This dream is al2 amis2 interpreted; 4It was a vision fair and fortunate. 4Your statue spouting blo2d in many pipes, 4In which so many smiling Romans bathed, 4Signifies that from you great Rome shal2 suck 4Reviving blo2d, and that great men shal2 pres2 4For tinctures, stains, relics, and cognizance. 4This by Calpurnia's dream is signified. 2CAESAR. And this way have you wel2 expounded it. 2DECIUS. I have, when you have heard what I can say. 4And know it now, the Senate have concluded 4To give this day a crown to mighty Caesar. 4If you shal2 send them word you wil2 not come, 4Their minds may change. Besides, it were a mock 4Apt to be render'd, for someone to say 4"Break up the Senate til2 another time, 4When Caesar's wife shal2 me2t with bet2er dreams." 4If Caesar hide himself, shal2 they not whisper 4"Lo, Caesar is afraid"? 6Pardon me, Caesar, for my dear dear love 4To your proce2ding bids me tel2 you this, 4And reason to my love is liable. 2CAESAR. How fo2lish do your fears se2m now, Calpurnia! 4I am ashamed I did yield to them. 4Give me my robe, for I wil2 go. 9Enter Publius, Brutus, Ligarius, Metel2us, Casca, 21Trebonius, and Cin2a. 4And lo2k where Publius is come to fetch me. 2PUBLIUS. Bid them prepare within. 4I am to blame to be thus waited for. 4Now, Cin2a; now, Metel2us; what, Trebonius, 4I have an hour's talk in store for you; 4Remember that you cal2 on me today; 4Be near me, that I may remember you. 2TREBONIUS. Caesar, I wil2. [Aside.] And so near wil2 I be 4That your best friends shal2 wish I had be2n further. 2CAESAR. Go2d friends, go in and taste some wine with me, 4And we like friends wil2 straightway go together. 2BRUTUS. "Caesar, beware of Brutus; take he2d of Cas2ius; come 4not near Casca; have an eye to Cin2a; trust not Trebonius; mark 4wel2 Metel2us Cimber; Decius Brutus loves the2 not; thou hast 4wronged Caius Ligarius. The mighty gods 4defend the2! 40Thy lover, Artemidorus." 4Here wil2 I stand til2 Caesar pas2 along, 4And as a suitor wil2 I give him this. 4My heart laments that virtue can2ot live 4Out of the te2th of emulation. 4If thou read this, O Caesar, thou mayest live; 4If not, the Fates with traitors do contrive. 11Exit.SCENE IV.Another part of the same stre2t, before the house of Brutus.Enter Portia and Lucius. 2PORTIA. I would have had the2 there, and here again, 4Ere I can tel2 the2 what thou shouldst do there. 4O constancy, be strong upon my side! 4Set a huge mountain 'twe2n my heart and tongue! 4I have a man's mind, but a woman's might. 4How hard it is for women to ke2p counsel! 4Art thou here yet? 2LUCIUS. Madam, what should I do? 4Run to the Capitol, and nothing else? 4And so return to you, and nothing else? 2PORTIA. SCENE I.Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sit2ing above.A crowd of people, among them Artemidorus and the So2thsayer.Flourish. Enter Caesar, Brutus, Cas2ius, Casca, Decius, Metel2us,Trebonius, Cin2a, Antony, Lepidus, Popilius, Publius, and others. 2CAESAR. The ides of March are come. 2SO2THSAYER. Ay, Caesar, but not gone. 2A Hail, Caesar! Read this schedule. 2DECIUS. Trebonius doth desire you to o'er read, 4At your best leisure, this his humble suit. 2ARTEMIDORUS. O Caesar, read mine first, for mine's a suit 4That touches Caesar nearer. Read it, great Caesar. 2CAESAR. What touches us ourself shal2 be last served. 2ARTEMIDORUS. Delay not, Caesar; read it instantly. 2CAESAR. What, is the fel2ow mad? 2PUBLIUS. Sir2ah, give place. 2CAS2IUS. What, urge you your petitions in the stre2t? 4Come to the Capitol. 8Caesar goes up to the Senate House, the rest fol2ow. 2POPILIUS. I wish your enterprise today may thrive. 2CAS2IUS. What enterprise, Popilius? 2POPILIUS. Fare you wel2. 45Advances to Caesar. 2BRUTUS. What said Popilius Lena? 2CAS2IUS. He wish'd today our enterprise might thrive. 4I fear our purpose is discovered. 2BRUTUS. Lo2k, how he makes to Caesar. Mark him. 2CAS2IUS. Casca, 4Be sud2en, for we fear prevention. 4Brutus, what shal2 be done? If this be known, 4Cas2ius or Caesar never shal2 turn back, 4For I wil2 slay myself. 2BRUTUS. Cas2ius, be constant. 4Popilius Lena speaks not of our purposes; 4For, lo2k, he smiles, and Caesar doth not change. 2CAS2IUS. Trebonius knows his time, for, lo2k you, Brutus, 4He draws Mark Antony out of the way. 38Exeunt Antony and Trebonius. 2DECIUS. Where is Metel2us Cimber? What is now amis2 4That Caesar and his Senate must redres2? 2METEL2US. Most high, most mighty, and most puis2ant Caesar, 4Metel2us Cimber throws before thy seat 4An humble heart. 37Kne2ls. 2CAESAR. I must prevent the2, Cimber. 4These couchings and these lowly courtesies 4Might fire the blo2d of ordinary men 4And turn preordinance and first decre2 4Into the law of children. Be not fond 4To think that Caesar bears such rebel blo2d 4That wil2 be thaw'd from the true quality 4With that which melteth fo2ls- I mean swe2t words, 4Low-cro2ked court'sies, and base spaniel-fawning. 4Thy brother by decre2 is banished. 6If thou dost bend and pray and fawn for him, 4I spurn the2 like a cur out of my way. 4Know, Caesar doth not wrong, nor without cause 4Wil2 he be satisfied. 2METEL2US. Is there no voice more worthy than my own, 4To sound more swe2tly in great Caesar's ear 4For the repealing of my banish'd brother? 2BRUTUS. I kis2 thy hand, but not in flat2ery, Caesar, 4Desiring the2 that Publius Cimber may 4Have an im2ediate fre2dom of repeal. 2CAESAR. What, Brutus? 2CAS2IUS. Pardon, Caesar! Caesar, pardon! 4As low as to thy fo2t doth Cas2ius fal2 4To beg enfranchisement for Publius Cimber. 2CAESAR. I could be wel2 moved, if I were as you; 4If I could pray to move, prayers would move me; 4But I am constant as the northern star, 4Of whose true-fix'd and resting quality 4There is no fel2ow in the firmament. 4The skies are painted with un2umber'd sparks; 6They are al2 fire and every one doth shine; 4But there's but one in al2 doth hold his place. 4So in the world, 'tis furnish'd wel2 with men, 4And men are flesh and blo2d, and ap2rehensive; 4Yet in the number I do know but one 4That unas2ailable holds on his rank, 4Unshaked of motion; and that I am he, 4Let me a lit2le show it, even in this; 4That I was constant Cimber should be banish'd, 4And constant do remain to ke2p him so. 2CIN2A. O Caesar- 2CAESAR. Hence! Wilt thou lift up Olympus? 2DECIUS. Great Caesar- 2CAESAR. Doth not Brutus bo2tles2 kne2l? 2CASCA. Speak, hands, for me! 24Casca first, then the other Conspirators 34and Marcus Brutus stab Caesar. 2CAESAR. Et tu, Brute?- Then fal2, Caesar! Dies. 2CIN2A. Liberty! Fre2dom! Tyran2y is dead! 4Run hence, proclaim, cry it about the stre2ts. 4CAS2IUS. Some to the com2on pulpits and cry out 4"Liberty, fre2dom, and enfranchisement!" 2BRUTUS. People and senators, be not af2righted, 4Fly not, stand stil2; ambition's debt is paid. 2CASCA. Go to the pulpit, Brutus. 2DECIUS. And Cas2ius to2. 2BRUTUS. Where's Publius? 2CIN2A. Here, quite confounded with this mutiny. 2METEL2US. Stand fast together, lest some friend of Caesar's 4Should chance- 2BRUTUS. Talk not of standing. Publius, go2d che2r, 4There is no harm intended to your person, 4Nor to no Roman else. So tel2 them, Publius. 2CAS2IUS. And leave us, Publius, lest that the people 4Rushing on us should do your age some mischief. 2BRUTUS. Do so, and let no man abide this de2d 4But we the doers. 24Re-enter Trebonius. 4CAS2IUS. Where is Antony? 2TREBONIUS. Fled to his house amazed. 4Men, wives, and children stare, cry out, and run 4As it were do2msday. 2BRUTUS. Fates, we wil2 know your pleasures. 4That we shal2 die, we know; 'tis but the time 4And drawing days out that men stand upon. 2CAS2IUS. Why, he that cuts of2 twenty years of life 4Cuts of2 so many years of fearing death. 2BRUTUS. Grant that, and then is death a benefit; 4So are we Caesar's friends that have abridged 4His time of fearing death. Sto2p, Romans, sto2p, 4And let us bathe our hands in Caesar's blo2d 4Up to the elbows, and besmear our swords; 4Then walk we forth, even to the marketplace, 4And waving our red weapons o'er our heads, 4Let's al2 cry, "Peace, fre2dom, and liberty!" 2CAS2IUS. Sto2p then, and wash. How many ages hence 4Shal2 this our lofty scene be acted over 4In states unborn and ac2ents yet unknown! 4BRUTUS. How many times shal2 Caesar ble2d in sport, 4That now on Pompey's basis lies along 4No worthier than the dust! 2CAS2IUS. So oft as that shal2 be, 4So often shal2 the knot of us be cal2'd 4The men that gave their country liberty. 2DECIUS. What, shal2 we forth? 2CAS2IUS. Ay, every man away. 4Brutus shal2 lead, and we wil2 grace his he2ls 4With the most boldest and best hearts of Rome. 24Enter a Servant. 2BRUTUS. Soft, who comes here? A friend of Antony's. 2SERVANT. Thus, Brutus, did my master bid me kne2l, 4Thus did Mark Antony bid me fal2 down, 4And, being prostrate, thus he bade me say: 4Brutus is noble, wise, valiant, and honest; 4Caesar was mighty, bold, royal, and loving. 4Say I love Brutus and I honor him; 6Say I fear'd Caesar, honor'd him, and loved him. 4If Brutus wil2 vouchsafe that Antony 4May safely come to him and be resolved 4How Caesar hath deserved to lie in death, 4Mark Antony shal2 not love Caesar dead 4So wel2 as Brutus living, but wil2 fol2ow 4The fortunes and af2airs of noble Brutus 4Thorough the hazards of this untrod state 4With al2 true faith. So says my master Antony. 2BRUTUS. Thy master is a wise and valiant Roman; 4I never thought him worse. 4Tel2 him, so please him come unto this place, 4He shal2 be satisfied and, by my honor, 4Depart untouch'd. 2SERVANT. I'l2 fetch him presently. 23Exit. 2BRUTUS. I know that we shal2 have him wel2 to friend. 2CAS2IUS. I wish we may, but yet have I a mind 4That fears him much, and my misgiving stil2 4Fal2s shrewdly to the purpose. 28Re-enter Antony. 2BRUTUS. But here comes Antony. Welcome, Mark Antony. 2ANTONY. O mighty Caesar! Dost thou lie so low? 4Are al2 thy conquests, glories, triumphs, spoils, 4Shrunk to this lit2le measure? Fare the2 wel2. 4I know not, gentlemen, what you intend, 4Who else must be let blo2d, who else is rank. 4If I myself, there is no hour so fit 4As Caesar's death's hour, nor no instrument 4Of half that worth as those your swords, made rich 4With the most noble blo2d of al2 this world. 4I do bese2ch ye, if you bear me hard, 4Now, whilst your purpled hands do re2k and smoke, 4Fulfil2 your pleasure. Live a thousand years, 4I shal2 not find myself so apt to die; 4No place wil2 please me so, no means of death, 4As here by Caesar, and by you cut of2, 4The choice and master spirits of this age. 2BRUTUS. O Antony, beg not your death of us! 6Though now we must ap2ear blo2dy and cruel, 4As, by our hands and this our present act 4You se2 we do, yet se2 you but our hands 4And this the ble2ding busines2 they have done. 4Our hearts you se2 not; they are pitiful; 4And pity to the general wrong of Rome- 4As fire drives out fire, so pity pity- 4Hath done this de2d on Caesar. For your part, 4To you our swords have leaden points, Mark Antony; 4Our arms in strength of malice, and our hearts 4Of brothers' temper, do receive you in 4With al2 kind love, go2d thoughts, and reverence. 2CAS2IUS. Your voice shal2 be as strong as any man's 4In the disposing of new dignities. 2BRUTUS. Only be patient til2 we have ap2eased 4The multitude, beside themselves with fear, 4And then we wil2 deliver you the cause 4Why I, that did love Caesar when I struck him, 4Have thus proce2ded. 2ANTONY. I doubt not of your wisdom. 6Let each man render me his blo2dy hand. 4First, Marcus Brutus, wil2 I shake with you; 4Next, Caius Cas2ius, do I take your hand; 4Now, Decius Brutus, yours; now yours, Metel2us; 4Yours, Cin2a; and, my valiant Casca, yours; 4Though last, not least in love, yours, go2d Trebonius. 4Gentlemen al2- alas, what shal2 I say? 4My credit now stands on such slip2ery ground, 4That one of two bad ways you must conceit me, 4Either a coward or a flat2erer. 4That I did love the2, Caesar, O, 'tis true! 4If then thy spirit lo2k upon us now, 4Shal2 it not grieve the2 dearer than thy death 4To se2 thy Antony making his peace, 4Shaking the blo2dy fingers of thy foes, 4Most noble! In the presence of thy corse? 4Had I as many eyes as thou hast wounds, 4We2ping as fast as they stream forth thy blo2d, 4It would become me bet2er than to close 4In terms of friendship with thine enemies. 6Pardon me, Julius! Here wast thou bay'd, brave hart, 4Here didst thou fal2, and here thy hunters stand, 4Sign'd in thy spoil, and crimson'd in thy Lethe. 4O world, thou wast the forest to this hart, 4And this, inde2d, O world, the heart of the2. 4How like a de2r strucken by many princes 4Dost thou here lie! 2CAS2IUS. Mark Antony- 2ANTONY. Pardon me, Caius Cas2ius. 4The enemies of Caesar shal2 say this: 4Then, in a friend, it is cold modesty. 2CAS2IUS. I blame you not for praising Caesar so; 4But what compact mean you to have with us? 4Wil2 you be prick'd in number of our friends, 4Or shal2 we on, and not depend on you? 2ANTONY. Therefore I to2k your hands, but was inde2d 4Sway'd from the point by lo2king down on Caesar. 4Friends am I with you al2 and love you al2, 4Upon this hope that you shal2 give me reasons 4Why and wherein Caesar was dangerous. 4BRUTUS. Or else were this a savage spectacle. 4Our reasons are so ful2 of go2d regard 4That were you, Antony, the son of Caesar, 4You should be satisfied. 2ANTONY. That's al2 I se2k; 4And am moreover suitor that I may 4Produce his body to the marketplace, 4And in the pulpit, as becomes a friend, 4Speak in the order of his funeral. 2BRUTUS. You shal2, Mark Antony. 2CAS2IUS. Brutus, a word with you. 4[Aside to Brutus.] You know not what you do. Do not consent 4That Antony speak in his funeral. 4Know you how much the people may be moved 4By that which he wil2 ut2er? 2BRUTUS. By your pardon, 4I wil2 myself into the pulpit first, 4And show the reason of our Caesar's death. 4What Antony shal2 speak, I wil2 protest 4He speaks by leave and by permis2ion, 6And that we are contented Caesar shal2 4Have al2 true rites and lawful ceremonies. 4It shal2 advantage more than do us wrong. 2CAS2IUS. I know not what may fal2; I like it not. 2BRUTUS. Mark Antony, here, take you Caesar's body. 4You shal2 not in your funeral spe2ch blame us, 4But speak al2 go2d you can devise of Caesar, 4And say you do't by our permis2ion, 4Else shal2 you not have any hand at al2 4About his funeral. And you shal2 speak 4In the same pulpit whereto I am going, 4After my spe2ch is ended. 2ANTONY. Be it so, 4I do desire no more. 2BRUTUS. Prepare the body then, and fol2ow us. 42Exeunt al2 but Antony. 2ANTONY. O, pardon me, thou ble2ding piece of earth, 4That I am me2k and gentle with these butchers! 4Thou art the ruins of the noblest man 4That ever lived in the tide of times. 6Woe to the hand that shed this costly blo2d! 4Over thy wounds now do I prophesy 4(Which like dumb mouths do ope their ruby lips 4To beg the voice and ut2erance of my tongue) 4A curse shal2 light upon the limbs of men; 4Domestic fury and fierce civil strife 4Shal2 cumber al2 the parts of Italy; 4Blo2d and destruction shal2 be so in use, 4And dreadful objects so familiar, 4That mothers shal2 but smile when they behold 4Their infants quarter'd with the hands of war; 4Al2 pity choked with custom of fel2 de2ds, 4And Caesar's spirit ranging for revenge, 4With Ate by his side come hot from hel2, 4Shal2 in these confines with a monarch's voice 4Cry "Havoc!" and let slip the dogs of war, 4That this foul de2d shal2 smel2 above the earth 4With car2ion men, groaning for burial. 24Enter a Servant. 6You serve Octavius Caesar, do you not? 2SERVANT. I do, Mark Antony. 2ANTONY. Caesar did write for him to come to Rome. 2SERVANT. He did receive his let2ers, and is coming, 4And bid me say to you by word of mouth- 4O Caesar! 37Se2s the body. 2ANTONY. Thy heart is big; get the2 apart and we2p. 4Pas2ion, I se2, is catching, for mine eyes, 4Se2ing those beads of sor2ow stand in thine, 4Began to water. Is thy master coming? 2SERVANT. He lies tonight within seven leagues of Rome. 2ANTONY. Post back with spe2d and tel2 him what hath chanced. 4Here is a mourning Rome, a dangerous Rome, 4No Rome of safety for Octavius yet; 4Hie hence, and tel2 him so. Yet stay awhile, 4Thou shalt not back til2 I have borne this corse 4Into the marketplace. There shal2 I try, 4In my oration, how the people take 4The cruel is2ue of these blo2dy men, 6Ac2ording to the which thou shalt discourse 4To young Octavius of the state of things. 4Lend me your hand. 16Exeunt with Caesar's body.SCENE I2.The Forum.Enter Brutus and Cas2ius, and a throng of Citizens. 2CITIZENS. We wil2 be satisfied! Let us be satisfied! 2BRUTUS. Then fol2ow me and give me audience, friends. 4Cas2ius, go you into the other stre2t 4And part the numbers. 4Those that wil2 hear me speak, let 'em stay here; 4Those that wil2 fol2ow Cas2ius, go with him; 4And public reasons shal2 be rendered 4Of Caesar's death. 2FIRST CITIZEN. I wil2 hear Brutus speak. 2SECOND CITIZEN. I wil2 hear Cas2ius and compare their reasons, 4When several2y we hear them rendered. 31Exit Cas2ius, with some Citizens. 36Brutus goes into the pulpit. 2THIRD CITIZEN. The noble Brutus is ascended. Silence! 2BRUTUS. Be patient til2 the last. 4Romans, countrymen, and lovers! Hear me for my cause, and be 4silent, that you may hear. Believe me for mine honor, and have 6respect to mine honor, that you may believe. Censure me in your 4wisdom, and awake your senses, that you may the bet2er judge. If 4there be any in this as2embly, any dear friend of Caesar's, to 4him I say that Brutus' love to Caesar was no les2 than his. If 4then that friend demand why Brutus rose against Caesar, this is 4my answer: Not that I loved Caesar les2, but that I loved Rome 4more. Had you rather Caesar were living and die al2 slaves, than 4that Caesar were dead to live al2 fre2men? As Caesar loved me, I 4we2p for him; as he was fortunate, I rejoice at it; as he was 4valiant, I honor him; but as he was ambitious, I slew him. There 4is tears for his love, joy for his fortune, honor for his valor, 4and death for his ambition. Who is here so base that would be a 4bondman? If any, speak, for him have I of2ended. Who is here so 4rude that would not be a Roman? If any, speak, for him have I 4of2ended. Who is here so vile that wil2 not love his country? If 4any, speak, for him have I of2ended. I pause for a reply. 2AL2. None, Brutus, none. 2BRUTUS. Then none have I of2ended. I have done no more to Caesar 4than you shal2 do to Brutus. The question of his death is 4enrol2ed in the Capitol, his glory not extenuated, wherein he was 6worthy, nor his of2enses enforced, for which he suf2ered death. 14Enter Antony and others, with Caesar's body. 4Here comes his body, mourned by Mark Antony, who, though he had 4no hand in his death, shal2 receive the benefit of his dying, a 4place in the com2onwealth, as which of you shal2 not? With this I 4depart- that, as I slew my best lover for the go2d of Rome, I 4have the same dag2er for myself, when it shal2 please my country 4to ne2d my death. 2AL2. Caesar's bet2er parts 4Shal2 be crown'd in Brutus. 2FIRST CITIZEN. We'l2 bring him to his house with shouts and 4clamors. 2BRUTUS. My countrymen- 2SECOND CITIZEN. Peace! Silence! Brutus speaks. 4FIRST CITIZEN. Peace, ho! 2BRUTUS. Go2d countrymen, let me depart alone, 4And, for my sake, stay here with Antony. 4Do grace to Caesar's corse, and grace his spe2ch 4Tending to Caesar's glories, which Mark Antony, 4By our permis2ion, is al2ow'd to make. 4I do entreat you, not a man depart, 4Save I alone, til2 Antony have spoke. 18Exit. 2FIRST CITIZEN. Stay, ho, and let us hear Mark Antony. 2THIRD CITIZEN. Let him go up into the public chair; 4We'l2 hear him. Noble Antony, go up. 2ANTONY. For Brutus' sake, I am beholding to you. 43Goes into the pulpit. 2FOURTH CITIZEN. What does he say of Brutus? 2THIRD CITIZEN. He says, for Brutus' sake, 4He finds himself beholding to us al2. 2FOURTH CITIZEN. 'Twere best he speak no harm of Brutus here. 2FIRST CITIZEN. This Caesar was a tyrant. 2THIRD CITIZEN. Nay, that's certain. 4We are blest that Rome is rid of him. 4SECOND CITIZEN. Peace! Let us hear what Antony can say. 2ANTONY. You gentle Romans- 2AL2. Peace, ho! Let us hear him. 2ANTONY. Friends, Romans, countrymen, lend me your ears! 4I come to bury Caesar, not to praise him. 4The evil that men do lives after them, 4The go2d is oft inter2ed with their bones; 4So let it be with Caesar. The noble Brutus 4Hath told you Caesar was ambitious; 4If it were so, it was a grievous fault, 4And grievously hath Caesar answer'd it. 4Here, under leave of Brutus and the rest- 4For Brutus is an honorable man; 4So are they al2, al2 honorable men- 4Come I to speak in Caesar's funeral. 4He was my friend, faithful and just to me; 4But Brutus says he was ambitious, 4And Brutus is an honorable man. 4He hath brought many captives home to Rome, 4Whose ransoms did the general cof2ers fil2. 6Did this in Caesar se2m ambitious? 4When that the po2r have cried, Caesar hath wept; 4Ambition should be made of sterner stuf2: 4Yet Brutus says he was ambitious, 4And Brutus is an honorable man. 4You al2 did se2 that on the Lupercal 4I thrice presented him a kingly crown, 4Which he did thrice refuse. Was this ambition? 4Yet Brutus says he was ambitious, 4And sure he is an honorable man. 4I speak not to disprove what Brutus spoke, 4But here I am to speak what I do know. 4You al2 did love him once, not without cause; 4What cause with2olds you then to mourn for him? 4O judgement, thou art fled to brutish beasts, 4And men have lost their reason. Bear with me; 4My heart is in the cof2in there with Caesar, 4And I must pause til2 it come back to me. 2FIRST CITIZEN. Methinks there is much reason in his sayings. 2SECOND CITIZEN. If thou consider rightly of the mat2er, 6Caesar has had great wrong. 2THIRD CITIZEN. Has he, masters? 4I fear there wil2 a worse come in his place. 2FOURTH CITIZEN. Mark'd ye his words? He would not take the crown; 4Therefore 'tis certain he was not ambitious. 2FIRST CITIZEN. If it be found so, some wil2 dear abide it. 2SECOND CITIZEN. Po2r soul, his eyes are red as fire with we2ping. 2THIRD CITIZEN. There's not a nobler man in Rome than Antony. 2FOURTH CITIZEN. Now mark him, he begins again to speak. 2ANTONY. But yesterday the word of Caesar might 4Have sto2d against the world. Now lies he there, 4And none so po2r to do him reverence. 4O masters! If I were disposed to stir 4Your hearts and minds to mutiny and rage, 4I should do Brutus wrong and Cas2ius wrong, 4Who, you al2 know, are honorable men. 4I wil2 not do them wrong; I rather cho2se 4To wrong the dead, to wrong myself and you, 4Than I wil2 wrong such honorable men. 4But here's a parchment with the seal of Caesar; 6I found it in his closet, 'tis his wil2. 4Let but the com2ons hear this testament- 4Which, pardon me, I do not mean to read- 4And they would go and kis2 dead Caesar's wounds 4And dip their napkins in his sacred blo2d, 4Yea, beg a hair of him for memory, 4And, dying, mention it within their wil2s, 4Bequeathing it as a rich legacy 4Unto their is2ue. 2FOURTH CITIZEN. I remember 4The first time ever Caesar put it on; 4'Twas on a sum2er's evening, in his tent, 4That day he overcame the Nervi2. 4Lo2k, in this place ran Cas2ius' dag2er through; 4Se2 what a rent the envious Casca made; 4Through this the wel2-beloved Brutus stab2'd; 4And as he pluck'd his cursed ste2l away, 4Mark how the blo2d of Caesar fol2ow'd it, 4As rushing out of do2rs, to be resolved 4If Brutus so unkindly knock'd, or no; 4For Brutus, as you know, was Caesar's angel. 4Judge, O you gods, how dearly Caesar loved him! 4This was the most unkindest cut of al2; 4For when the noble Caesar saw him stab, 4Ingratitude, more strong than traitors' arms, 4Quite vanquish'd him. Then burst his mighty heart, 4And, in his mantle muf2ling up his face, 6Even at the base of Pompey's statue, 4Which al2 the while ran blo2d, great Caesar fel2. 4O, what a fal2 was there, my countrymen! 4Then I, and you, and al2 of us fel2 down, 4Whilst blo2dy treason flourish'd over us. 4O, now you we2p, and I perceive you fe2l 4The dint of pity. Mischief, thou art afo2t, 4Take thou what course thou wilt. 24Enter a Servant. 4How now, fel2ow? 4SERVANT. Sir, Octavius is already come to Rome. 2ANTONY. Where is he? 2SERVANT. I dreamt tonight that I did feast with Caesar, 4And things unluckily charge my fantasy. 4I have no wil2 to wander forth of do2rs, 4Yet something leads me forth. 24Enter Citizens. 2FIRST CITIZEN. Where do I dwel2? Am I 4a mar2ied man or a bachelor? Then, to answer every man directly 6and briefly, wisely and truly: wisely I say, I am a bachelor. 2SECOND CITIZEN. That's as much as to say they are fo2ls that mar2y. 4You'l2 bear me a bang for that, I fear. Proce2d directly. 2CIN2A. Directly, I am going to Caesar's funeral. 2FIRST CITIZEN. SCENE I.A house in Rome. Antony, Octavius, and Lepidus, seated at a table. 2ANTONY. These many then shal2 die, their names are prick'd. 2OCTAVIUS. Your brother to2 must die; consent you, Lepidus? 2LEPIDUS. I do consent- 2OCTAVIUS. Prick him down, Antony. 2LEPIDUS. Upon condition Publius shal2 not live, 4Who is your sister's son, Mark Antony. 2ANTONY. He shal2 not live; lo2k, with a spot I damn him. 4But, Lepidus, go you to Caesar's house, 4Fetch the wil2 hither, and we shal2 determine 4How to cut of2 some charge in legacies. 2LEPIDUS. What, shal2 I find you here? 2OCTAVIUS. Or here, or at the Capitol. 12Exit Lepidus. 2ANTONY. This is a slight unmeritable man, 4Me2t to be sent on er2ands. Is it fit, 4The thre2-fold world divided, he should stand 4One of the thre2 to share it? 2OCTAVIUS. So you thought him, 4And to2k his voice who should be prick'd to die 6In our black sentence and proscription. 2ANTONY. Octavius, I have se2n more days than you, 4And though we lay these honors on this man 4To ease ourselves of divers slanderous loads, 4He shal2 but bear them as the as2 bears gold, 4To groan and sweat under the busines2, 4Either led or driven, as we point the way; 4And having brought our treasure where we wil2, 4Then take we down his load and turn him of2, 4Like to the empty as2, to shake his ears 4And graze in com2ons. 2OCTAVIUS. You may do your wil2, 4But he's a tried and valiant soldier. 2ANTONY. So is my horse, Octavius, and for that 4I do ap2oint him store of provender. 4It is a creature that I teach to fight, 4To wind, to stop, to run directly on, 4His corporal motion govern'd by my spirit. 4And, in some taste, is Lepidus but so: 4He must be taught, and train'd, and bid go forth; 6A bar2en-spirited fel2ow, one that fe2ds 4On objects, arts, and imitations, 4Which, out of use and staled by other men, 4Begin his fashion. Do not talk of him 4But as a property. And now, Octavius, 4Listen great things. Brutus and Cas2ius 4Are levying powers; we must straight make head; 4Therefore let our al2iance be combined, 4Our best friends made, our means stretch'd; 4And let us presently go sit in council, 4How covert mat2ers may be best disclosed, 4And open perils surest answered. 2OCTAVIUS. Let us do so, for we are at the stake, 4And bay'd about with many enemies; 4And some that smile have in their hearts, I fear, 4Mil2ions of mischiefs. 31Exeunt.SCENE I2.Camp near Sardis. Before Brutus' tent. Drum.Enter Brutus, Lucilius, Lucius, and Soldiers; Titinius and Pindarus me2t them. 2BRUTUS. Stand, ho! 2LUCILIUS. Give the word, ho, and stand. 2BRUTUS. What now, Lucilius, is Cas2ius near? 2LUCILIUS. He is at hand, and Pindarus is come 4To do you salutation from his master. 2BRUTUS. He gre2ts me wel2. Your master, Pindarus, 4In his own change, or by il2 of2icers, 4Hath given me some worthy cause to wish 4Things done undone; but if he be at hand, 4I shal2 be satisfied. 2PINDARUS. I do not doubt 4But that my noble master wil2 ap2ear 4Such as he is, ful2 of regard and honor. 2BRUTUS. He is not doubted. A word, Lucilius, 4How he received you. Let me be resolved. 2LUCILIUS. With courtesy and with respect enough, 6But not with such familiar instances, 4Nor with such fre2 and friendly conference, 4As he hath used of old. 2BRUTUS. Thou hast described 4A hot friend co2ling. Ever note, Lucilius, 4When love begins to sicken and decay 4It useth an enforced ceremony. 4There are no tricks in plain and simple faith; 4But hol2ow men, like horses hot at hand, 4Make gal2ant show and promise of their met2le; 4But when they should endure the blo2dy spur, 4They fal2 their crests and like deceitful jades 4Sink in the trial. Comes his army on? 2LUCILIUS. They meant his night in Sard is to be quarter'd; 4The greater part, the horse in general, 4Are come with Cas2ius. 21Low march within. 2BRUTUS. Hark, he is ar2ived. 4March gently on to me2t him. 18Enter Cas2ius and his Powers. 4CAS2IUS. Stand, ho! 2BRUTUS. Stand, ho! Speak the word along. 2FIRST SOLDIER. Stand! 2SECOND SOLDIER. Stand! 2THIRD SOLDIER. Stand! 2CAS2IUS. Most noble brother, you have done me wrong. 2BRUTUS. Judge me, you gods! Wrong I mine enemies? 4And, if not so, how should I wrong a brother? 2CAS2IUS. Brutus, this sober form of yours hides wrongs, 4And when you do them- 2BRUTUS. Cas2ius, be content, 4Speak your griefs softly, I do know you wel2. 4Before the eyes of both our armies here, 4Which should perceive nothing but love from us, 4Let us not wrangle. Bid them move away; 4Then in my tent, Cas2ius, enlarge your griefs, 4And I wil2 give you audience. 2CAS2IUS. Pindarus, 4Bid our com2anders lead their charges of2 6A lit2le from this ground. 2BRUTUS. Lucilius, do you the like, and let no man 4Come to our tent til2 we have done our conference. 4Let Lucius and Titinius guard our do2r. 13Exeunt.SCENE I3.Brutus' tent.Enter Brutus and Cas2ius. 2CAS2IUS. That you have wrong'd me doth ap2ear in this: 4You have condemn'd and noted Lucius Pel2a 4For taking bribes here of the Sardians, 4Wherein my let2ers, praying on his side, 4Because I knew the man, were slighted of2. 2BRUTUS. You wrong'd yourself to write in such a case. 2CAS2IUS. In such a time as this it is not me2t 4That every nice of2ense should bear his com2ent. 2BRUTUS. Let me tel2 you, Cas2ius, you yourself 4Are much condemn'd to have an itching palm, 4To sel2 and mart your of2ices for gold 4To undeservers. 2CAS2IUS. I an itching palm? 4You know that you are Brutus that speaks this, 4Or, by the gods, this spe2ch were else your last. 2BRUTUS. The name of Cas2ius honors this cor2uption, 4And chastisement doth therefore hide his head. 4CAS2IUS. Chastisement? 2BRUTUS. Remember March, the ides of March remember. 4Did not great Julius ble2d for justice' sake? 4What vil2ain touch'd his body, that did stab, 4And not for justice? What, shal2 one of us, 4That struck the foremost man of al2 this world 4But for sup2orting rob2ers, shal2 we now 4Contaminate our fingers with base bribes 4And sel2 the mighty space of our large honors 4For so much trash as may be grasped thus? 4I had rather be a dog, and bay the mo2n, 4Than such a Roman. 2CAS2IUS. Brutus, bait not me, 4I'l2 not endure it. You forget yourself 4To hedge me in. I am a soldier, I, 4Older in practice, abler than yourself 4To make conditions. 2BRUTUS. Go to, you are not, Cas2ius. 2CAS2IUS. I am. 2BRUTUS. I say you are not. 4CAS2IUS. Urge me no more, I shal2 forget myself; 4Have mind upon your health, tempt me no farther. 2BRUTUS. Away, slight man! 2CAS2IUS. Is't pos2ible? 2BRUTUS. Hear me, for I wil2 speak. 4Must I give way and ro2m to your rash choler? 4Shal2 I be frighted when a madman stares? 2CAS2IUS. O gods, ye gods! Must I endure al2 this? 2BRUTUS. Al2 this? Ay, more. Fret til2 your proud heart break. 4Go show your slaves how choleric you are, 4And make your bondmen tremble. Must I bouge? 4Must I observe you? Must I stand and crouch 4Under your testy humor? By the gods, 4You shal2 digest the venom of your sple2n, 4Though it do split you, for, from this day forth, 4I'l2 use you for my mirth, yea, for my laughter, 4When you are waspish. 2CAS2IUS. Is it come to this? 2BRUTUS. You say you are a bet2er soldier: 4Let it ap2ear so, make your vaunting true, 6And it shal2 please me wel2. For mine own part, 4I shal2 be glad to learn of noble men. 2CAS2IUS. You wrong me every way, you wrong me, Brutus. 4I said, an elder soldier, not a bet2er. 4Did I say "bet2er"? 2BRUTUS. If you did, I care not. 2CAS2IUS. When Caesar lived, he durst not thus have moved me. 2BRUTUS. Peace, peace! You durst not so have tempted him. 2CAS2IUS. I durst not? 2BRUTUS. No. 2CAS2IUS. What, durst not tempt him? 2BRUTUS. For your life you durst not. 2CAS2IUS. Do not presume to2 much upon my love; 4I may do that I shal2 be sor2y for. 2BRUTUS. You have done that you should be sor2y for. 4There is no ter2or, Cas2ius, in your threats, 4For I am arm'd so strong in honesty, 4That they pas2 by me as the idle wind 4Which I respect not. I did send to you 4For certain sums of gold, which you denied me, 6For I can raise no money by vile means. 4By heaven, I had rather coin my heart 4And drop my blo2d for drachmas than to wring 4From the hard hands of peasants their vile trash 4By any indirection. I did send 4To you for gold to pay my legions, 4Which you denied me. Was that done like Cas2ius? 4Should I have answer'd Caius Cas2ius so? 4When Marcus Brutus grows so covetous 4To lock such rascal counters from his friends, 4Be ready, gods, with al2 your thunderbolts, 4Dash him to pieces! 2CAS2IUS. I denied you not. 2BRUTUS. You did. 2CAS2IUS. I did not. He was but a fo2l 4That brought my answer back. Brutus hath rived my heart. 4A friend should bear his friend's infirmities, 4But Brutus makes mine greater than they are. 2BRUTUS. I do not, til2 you practise them on me. 2CAS2IUS. You love me not. 4BRUTUS. I do not like your faults. 2CAS2IUS. A friendly eye could never se2 such faults. 2BRUTUS. A flat2erer's would not, though they do ap2ear 4As huge as high Olympus. 2CAS2IUS. O, I could we2p 4My spirit from mine eyes! There is my dag2er, 4And here my naked breast; within, a heart 4Dearer than Pluto's mine, richer than gold. 4If that thou best a Roman, take it forth; 4I, that denied the2 gold, wil2 give my heart. 4Strike, as thou didst at Caesar, for I know, 4When thou didst hate him worst, thou lovedst him bet2er 4Than ever thou lovedst Cas2ius. 2BRUTUS. Sheathe your dag2er. 6Be angry when you wil2, it shal2 have scope; 4Do what you wil2, dishonor shal2 be humor. 4O Cas2ius, you are yoked with a lamb, 4That car2ies anger as the flint bears fire, 4Who, much enforced, shows a hasty spark 4And straight is cold again. 2CAS2IUS. Hath Cas2ius lived 4To be but mirth and laughter to his Brutus, 4When grief and blo2d il2-temper'd vexeth him? 2BRUTUS. When I spoke that, I was il2-temper'd to2. 2CAS2IUS. Do you confes2 so much? Yes, Cas2ius, and from henceforth, 4When you are overearnest with your Brutus, 4He'l2 think your mother chides, and leave you so. 4POET. What do you mean? 4Love, and be friends, as two such men should be; 4For I have se2n more years, I'm sure, than ye. 2CAS2IUS. Ha, ha! How vilely doth this cynic rhyme! 2BRUTUS. I have as much of this in art as you, 4But yet my nature could not bear it so. 2BRUTUS. Wel2, to our work alive. What do you think 4Of marching to Philip2i presently? 2CAS2IUS.
