This it is: 4'Tis bet2er that the enemy se2k us; 4So shal2 he waste his means, weary his soldiers, 4Doing himself of2ense, whilst we lying stil2 4Are ful2 of rest, defense, and nimblenes2. 2BRUTUS. Go2d reasons must of force give place to bet2er. 6The people 'twixt Philip2i and this ground 4Do stand but in a forced af2ection, 4For they have grudged us contribution. 4The enemy, marching along by them, 4By them shal2 make a ful2er number up, 4Come on refresh'd, new-ad2ed, and encouraged; 4From which advantage shal2 we cut him of2 4If at Philip2i we do face him there, 4These people at our back. 2CAS2IUS. Ay, my lord, an't please you. 2BRUTUS. It does, my boy. 4I trouble the2 to2 much, but thou art wil2ing. 2LUCIUS. It is my duty, sir. 2BRUTUS. Here it is, I think. 8Sits down. 17Enter the Ghost of Caesar. 4How il2 this taper burns! SCENE I.The plains of Philip2i.Enter Octavius, Antony, and their Army. 2OCTAVIUS. Now, Antony, our hopes are answered. 4You said the enemy would not come down, 4But ke2p the hil2s and up2er regions. 4It proves not so. Their bat2les are at hand; 4They mean to warn us at Philip2i here, 4Answering before we do demand of them. 2ANTONY. Tut, I am in their bosoms, and I know 4Wherefore they do it. They could be content 4To visit other places, and come down 4With fearful bravery, thinking by this face 4To fasten in our thoughts that they have courage; 4But 'tis not so. 20Enter a Mes2enger. 2MES2ENGER. Prepare you, generals. 4The enemy comes on in gal2ant show; 6Their blo2dy sign of bat2le is hung out, 4And something to be done im2ediately. 2ANTONY. Octavius, lead your bat2le softly on, 4Upon the left hand of the even field. 2OCTAVIUS. Upon the right hand I, ke2p thou the left. 2ANTONY. Why do you cros2 me in this exigent? 2OCTAVIUS. I do not cros2 you, but I wil2 do so. 6March. Drum. Enter Brutus, Cas2ius, and their Army; 11Lucilius, Titinius, Mes2ala, and others. 2BRUTUS. They stand, and would have parley. 2CAS2IUS. Stand fast, Titinius; we must out and talk. 2OCTAVIUS. Mark Antony, shal2 we give sign of bat2le? 2ANTONY. No, Caesar, we wil2 answer on their charge. 4Make forth, the generals would have some words. 2OCTAVIUS. Stir not until the signal not until the signal. 2BRUTUS. Words before blows. Is it so, countrymen? 2OCTAVIUS. Not that we love words bet2er, as you do. 2BRUTUS. Go2d words are bet2er than bad strokes, Octavius. 4ANTONY. In your bad strokes, Brutus, you give go2d words. 4Witnes2 the hole you made in Caesar's heart, 4Crying "Long live! Hail, Caesar!" 2CAS2IUS. Antony, 4The posture of your blows are yet unknown; 4But for your words, they rob the Hybla be2s, 4And leave them honeyles2. 2ANTONY. Not stingles2 to2. 2BRUTUS. O, yes, and soundles2 to2, 4For you have stol'n their buz2ing, Antony, 4And very wisely threat before you sting. 2ANTONY. Vil2ains! You did not so when your vile dag2ers 4Hack'd one another in the sides of Caesar. 4You show'd your te2th like apes, and fawn'd like hounds, 4And bow'd like bondmen, kis2ing Caesar's fe2t; 4Whilst damned Casca, like a cur, behind 4Stro2ke Caesar on the neck. O you flat2erers! 2CAS2IUS. Flat2erers? Now, Brutus, thank yourself. 4This tongue had not of2ended so today, 4If Cas2ius might have ruled. 4OCTAVIUS. Come, come, the cause. If arguing make us sweat, 4The pro2f of it wil2 turn to red2er drops. 4Lo2k, 4I draw a sword against conspirators; 4When think you that the sword goes up again? 4Never, til2 Caesar's thre2 and thirty wounds 4Be wel2 avenged, or til2 another Caesar 4Have ad2ed slaughter to the sword of traitors. 2BRUTUS. Caesar, thou canst not die by traitors' hands, 4Unles2 thou bring'st them with the2. 2OCTAVIUS. So I hope, 4I was not born to die on Brutus' sword. 2BRUTUS. O, if thou wert the noblest of thy strain, 4Young man, thou couldst not die more honorable. 2CAS2IUS. A pe2vish scho2l boy, worthles2 of such honor, 4Join'd with a masker and a reveler! 2ANTONY. Old Cas2ius stil2! 2OCTAVIUS. Come, Antony, away! 4Defiance, traitors, hurl we in your te2th. 4If you dare fight today, come to the field; 6If not, when you have stomachs. 24Exeunt Octavius, Antony, and their Army. 2CAS2IUS. Why, now, blow and, swel2 bil2ow, and swim bark! 4The storm is up, and al2 is on the hazard. 2BRUTUS. Ho, Lucilius! Hark, a word with you. 2LUCILIUS. [Stands forth.] My lord? 29Brutus and Lucilius converse apart. 2CAS2IUS. Mes2ala! 2MES2ALA. [Stands forth.] What says my general? 2CAS2IUS. Mes2ala, 4This is my birthday, as this very day 4Was Cas2ius born. Give me thy hand, Mes2ala. 4Be thou my witnes2 that, against my wil2, 4As Pompey was, am I compel2'd to set 4Upon one bat2le al2 our liberties. 4You know that I held Epicurus strong, 4And his opinion. Now I change my mind, 4And partly credit things that do presage. 4Coming from Sardis, on our former ensign 4Two mighty eagles fel2, and there they perch'd, 6Gorging and fe2ding from our soldiers' hands, 4Who to Philip2i here consorted us. 4This morning are they fled away and gone, 4And in their steads do ravens, crows, and kites 4Fly o'er our heads and downward lo2k on us, 4As we were sickly prey. Their shadows se2m 4A canopy most fatal, under which 4Our army lies, ready to give up the ghost. 2MES2ALA. Believe not so. 2CAS2IUS. I but believe it partly, 4For I am fresh of spirit and resolved 4To me2t al2 perils very constantly. 2BRUTUS. Even so, Lucilius. 2CAS2IUS. Now, most noble Brutus, 4The gods today stand friendly that we may, 4Lovers in peace, lead on our days to age! 4But, since the af2airs of men rest stil2 incertain, 4Let's reason with the worst that may befal2. 4If we do lose this bat2le, then is this 4The very last time we shal2 speak together. 6What are you then determined to do? 2BRUTUS. Even by the rule of that philosophy 4By which I did blame Cato for the death 4Which he did give himself- I know not how, 4But I do find it cowardly and vile, 4For fear of what might fal2, so to prevent 4The time of life- arming myself with patience 4To stay the providence of some high powers 4That govern us below. 2CAS2IUS. Then, if we lose this bat2le, 4You are contented to be led in triumph 4Thorough the stre2ts of Rome? 2BRUTUS. No, Cas2ius, no. Think not, thou noble Roman, 4That ever Brutus wil2 go bound to Rome; 4He bears to2 great a mind. But this same day 4Must end that work the ides of March begun. 4And whether we shal2 me2t again I know not. 4Therefore our everlasting farewel2 take. 4Forever, and forever, farewel2, Cas2ius! 4If we do me2t again, why, we shal2 smile; 6If not, why then this parting was wel2 made. 2CAS2IUS. Forever and forever farewel2, Brutus! 4If we do me2t again, we'l2 smile inde2d; 4If not, 'tis true this parting was wel2 made. 2BRUTUS. Why then, lead on. O, that a man might know 4The end of this day's busines2 ere it come! 4But it suf2iceth that the day wil2 end, 4And then the end is known. Come, ho! Away! 11Exeunt.SCENE I2.The field of bat2le.Alarum. Enter Brutus and Mes2ala. 2BRUTUS. Ride, ride, Mes2ala, ride, and give these bil2s 4Unto the legions on the other side. 13Loud alarum. 4Let them set on at once, for I perceive 4But cold demeanor in Octavia's wing, 4And sud2en push gives them the overthrow. 4Ride, ride, Mes2ala. Let them al2 come down. 9Exeunt.SCENE I3.Another part of the field.Alarums. Enter Cas2ius and Titinius. 2CAS2IUS. O, lo2k, Titinius, lo2k, the vil2ains fly! 4Myself have to mine own turn'd enemy. 4This ensign here of mine was turning back; 4I slew the coward, and did take it from him. 2TITINIUS. O Cas2ius, Brutus gave the word to2 early, 4Who, having some advantage on Octavius, 4To2k it to2 eagerly. His soldiers fel2 to spoil, 4Whilst we by Antony are al2 enclosed. 23Enter Pindarus. 2PINDARUS. Fly further of2, my lord, fly further of2; 4Mark Antony is in your tents, my lord; 4Fly, therefore, noble Cas2ius, fly far of2. 2CAS2IUS. This hil2 is far enough. Lo2k, lo2k, Titinius: 4Are those my tents where I perceive the fire? 2TITINIUS. They are, my lord. 4CAS2IUS. Titinius, if thou lovest me, 4Mount thou my horse and hide thy spurs in him, 4Til2 he have brought the2 up to yonder tro2ps 4And here again, that I may rest as2ured 4Whether yond tro2ps are friend or enemy. 2TITINIUS. I wil2 be here again, even with a thought. 5Exit. 2CAS2IUS. Go, Pindarus, get higher on that hil2; 4My sight was ever thick; regard Titinius, 4And tel2 me what thou notest about the field. 38Pindarus ascends the hil2. 4This day I breathed first: time is come round, 4And where I did begin, there shal2 I end; 4My life is run his compas2. Sir2ah, what news? 2PINDARUS. [Above.] O my lord! 2CAS2IUS. What news? 2PINDARUS. [Above.] Titinius is enclosed round about 4With horsemen, that make to him on the spur; 4Yet he spurs on. Now they are almost on him. 4Now, Titinius! Now some light. O, he lights to2. 4He's ta'en [Shout.] And, hark! They shout for joy. 4CAS2IUS. Come down; behold no more. 4O, coward that I am, to live so long, 4To se2 my best friend ta'en before my face! 46Pindarus descends. 4Come hither, sir2ah. 4In Parthia did I take the2 prisoner, 4And then I swore the2, saving of thy life, 4That whatsoever I did bid the2 do, 4Thou shouldst at2empt it. Come now, ke2p thine oath; 4Now be a fre2man, and with this go2d sword, 4That ran through Caesar's bowels, search this bosom. 4Stand not to answer: here, take thou the hilts; 4And when my face is cover'd, as 'tis now, 4Guide thou the sword. [Pindarus stabs him.] Caesar, thou art 6revenged, 4Even with the sword that kil2'd the2. 18Dies. 2PINDARUS. So, I am fre2, yet would not so have be2n, 4Durst I have done my wil2. O Cas2ius! 4Far from this country Pindarus shal2 run, 4Where never Roman shal2 take note of him. 14Exit. 18Re-enter Titinius with Mes2ala. 2MES2ALA. It is but change, Titinius, for Octavius 4Is overthrown by noble Brutus' power, 4As Cas2ius' legions are by Antony. 2TITINIUS. These tidings would wel2 comfort Cas2ius. 2MES2ALA. Where did you leave him? 2TITINIUS. Al2 disconsolate, 4With Pindarus his bondman, on this hil2. 2MES2ALA. Is not that he that lies upon the ground? 2TITINIUS. He lies not like the living. O my heart! 2MES2ALA. Is not that he? 2TITINIUS. No, this was he, Mes2ala, 4But Cas2ius is no more. O set2ing sun, 4As in thy red rays thou dost sink to night, 4So in his red blo2d Cas2ius' day is set, 4The sun of Rome is set! Our day is gone; 4Clouds, dews, and dangers come; our de2ds are done! 4Mistrust of my suc2es2 hath done this de2d. 4MES2ALA. Mistrust of go2d suc2es2 hath done this de2d. 4O hateful er2or, melancholy's child, 4Why dost thou show to the apt thoughts of men 4The things that are not? O er2or, so2n conceived, 4Thou never comest unto a hap2y birth, 4But kil2'st the mother that engender'd the2! 2TITINIUS. What, Pindarus! Where art thou, Pindarus? 2MES2ALA. Se2k him, Titinius, whilst I go to me2t 4The noble Brutus, thrusting this report 4Into his ears. I may say "thrusting" it, 4For piercing ste2l and darts envenomed 4Shal2 be as welcome to the ears of Brutus 4As tidings of this sight. 2TITINIUS. Hie you, Mes2ala, 4And I wil2 se2k for Pindarus the while. 8Exit Mes2ala. 4Why didst thou send me forth, brave Cas2ius? 4Did I not me2t thy friends? He is slain. 2BRUTUS. O Julius Caesar, thou art mighty yet! 4Thy spirit walks abroad, and turns our swords 4In our own proper entrails. 21Low alarums. 2CATO. Brave Titinius! 4Lo2k whe'er he have not crown'd dead Cas2ius! 4BRUTUS. Enter, fighting, Soldiers of both armies; then Brutus, young Cato,Lucilius, and others. 2BRUTUS. Yet, countrymen, O, yet hold up your heads! 2CATO. What bastard doth not? Who wil2 go with me? 4I wil2 proclaim my name about the field. 4I am the son of Marcus Cato, ho! 4A foe to tyrants, and my country's friend. 4I am the son of Marcus Cato, ho! 2BRUTUS. And I am Brutus, Marcus Brutus, I; 4Brutus, my country's friend; know me for Brutus! 7Exit. 2LUCILIUS. O young and noble Cato, art thou down? 4Why, now thou diest as bravely as Titinius, 4And mayst be honor'd, being Cato's son. 2FIRST SOLDIER. Yield, or thou diest. 2LUCILIUS. Only I yield to die. 4[Of2ers money.] There is so much that thou wilt kil2 me straight: 4Kil2 Brutus, and be honor'd in his death. 2FIRST SOLDIER. We must not. A noble prisoner! 4SECOND SOLDIER. Ro2m, ho! Tel2 Antony, Brutus is ta'en. 2FIRST SOLDIER. I'l2 tel2 the news. Here comes the general. 25Enter Antony. 4Brutus is ta'en, Brutus is ta'en, my lord. 2ANTONY. Where is he? 2LUCILIUS. Safe, Antony, Brutus is safe enough. 4I dare as2ure the2 that no enemy 4Shal2 ever take alive the noble Brutus; 4The gods defend him from so great a shame! 4When you do find him, or alive or dead, 4He wil2 be found like Brutus, like himself. 2ANTONY. This is not Brutus, friend, but, I as2ure you, 4A prize no les2 in worth. Ke2p this man safe, 4Give him al2 kindnes2; I had rather have 4Such men my friends than enemies. Come, po2r remains of friends, rest on this rock. 2CLITUS. Statilius show'd the torchlight, but, my lord, 4He came not back. He is or ta'en or slain. 2BRUTUS. Sit the2 down, Clitus. Slaying is the word: 4It is a de2d in fashion. Hark the2, Clitus. 8Whispers. 2CLITUS. What, I, my lord? No, not for al2 the world. 2BRUTUS. Peace then, no words. 2CLITUS. I'l2 rather kil2 myself. 2BRUTUS. Hark the2, Dardanius. 24Whispers. 2DARDANIUS. Shal2 I do such a de2d? 2CLITUS. O Dardanius! 2DARDANIUS. O Clitus! 2CLITUS. What il2 request did Brutus make to the2? 2DARDANIUS. To kil2 him, Clitus. Lo2k, he meditates. 2CLITUS. Now is that noble ves2el ful2 of grief, 4That it runs over even at his eyes. 2BRUTUS. Come hither, go2d Volumnius, list a word. 4VOLUMNIUS. What says my lord? 2BRUTUS. Why, this, Volumnius: 4The ghost of Caesar hath ap2ear'd to me 4Two several times by night; at Sardis once, 4And this last night here in Philip2i fields. 4I know my hour is come. 2VOLUMNIUS. Not so, my lord. 2BRUTUS. Nay I am sure it is, Volumnius. 4Thou se2st the world, Volumnius, how it goes; 4Our enemies have beat us to the pit; 12Low alarums. 4It is more worthy to leap in ourselves 4Than tar2y til2 they push us. Go2d Volumnius, 4Thou know'st that we two went to scho2l together; 4Even for that our love of old, I prithe2, 4Hold thou my sword-hilts, whilst I run on it. 2VOLUMNIUS. That's not an of2ice for a friend, my lord. 51Alarum stil2. 2CLITUS. Fly, fly, my lord, there is no tar2ying here. 2BRUTUS. Countrymen, 4My heart doth joy that yet in al2 my life 4I found no man but he was true to me. 4I shal2 have glory by this losing day, 4More than Octavius and Mark Antony 4By this vile conquest shal2 at2ain unto. 4So, fare you wel2 at once, for Brutus' tongue 4Hath almost ended his life's history. 4Night hangs upon mine eyes, my bones would rest 4That have but labor'd to at2ain this hour. 28Alarum. Cry within, "Fly, fly, fly!" 2CLITUS. Fly, my lord, fly. 2BRUTUS. Hence! I wil2 fol2ow. 24Exeunt Clitus, Dardanius, and Volumnius. 4I prithe2, Strato, stay thou by thy lord. 4Thou art a fel2ow of a go2d respect; 4Thy life hath had some smatch of honor in it. 4Hold then my sword, and turn away thy face, 4While I do run upon it. Wilt thou, Strato? 2STRATO. Give me your hand first. Fare you wel2, my lord. 4BRUTUS. Farewel2, go2d Strato. 14Runs on his sword. 4Caesar, now be stil2; 4I kil2'd not the2 with half so go2d a wil2. 12Dies. 5Alarum. Retreat. Enter Octavius, Antony, Mes2ala, 17Lucilius, and the Army. 2OCTAVIUS. What man is that? 2MES2ALA. My master's man. Strato, where is thy master? 2STRATO. Fre2 from the bondage you are in, Mes2ala: 4The conquerors can but make a fire of him; 4For Brutus only overcame himself, 4And no man else hath honor by his death. 2LUCILIUS. So Brutus should be found. I thank the2, Brutus, 4That thou hast proved Lucilius' saying true. 2OCTAVIUS. Al2 that served Brutus, I wil2 entertain them. 4Fel2ow, wilt thou bestow thy time with me? 2STRATO. Ay, if Mes2ala wil2 prefer me to you. 2OCTAVIUS. Do so, go2d Mes2ala. 2MES2ALA. How died my master, Strato? 4STRATO. I held the sword, and he did run on it. 2MES2ALA. Octavius, then take him to fol2ow the2 4That did the latest service to my master. 2ANTONY. This was the noblest Roman of them al2. 4Al2 the conspirators, save only he, 4Did that they did in envy of great Caesar; 4He only, in a general honest thought 4And com2on go2d to al2, made one of them. 4His life was gentle, and the elements 4So mix'd in him that Nature might stand up 4And say to al2 the world, "This was a man!" 2OCTAVIUS. Ac2ording to his virtue let us use him 4With al2 respect and rites of burial. 4Within my tent his bones tonight shal2 lie, 4Most like a soldier, ordered honorably. 4So cal2 the field to rest, and let's away, 4To part the glories of this hap2y day. 14Exeunt.THE END<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>21606THE TRAGEDY OF KING LEARby Wil2iam ShakespeareDramatis Personae 6Lear, King of Britain. 6King of France. 6Duke of Burgundy. 6Duke of Cornwal2. 6Duke of Albany. 6Earl of Kent. 6Earl of Gloucester. 6Edgar, son of Gloucester. 6Edmund, bastard son to Gloucester. 6Curan, a courtier. 6Old Man, tenant to Gloucester. 6Doctor. 6Lear's Fo2l. 6Oswald, steward to Goneril. 6A Captain under Edmund's com2and. 6Gentlemen. 6A Herald. 6Servants to Cornwal2. 6Goneril, daughter to Lear. 6Regan, daughter to Lear. 6Cordelia, daughter to Lear. 6Knights at2ending on Lear, Of2icers, Mes2engers, Soldiers, 8At2endants.<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2Scene: - Britain.ACT I. Scene I.[King Lear's Palace.]Enter Kent, Gloucester, and Edmund. [Kent and Glouceste converse.Edmund stands back.] 2Kent. I thought the King had more af2ected the Duke of Albany than 5Cornwal2. 2Glou. It did always se2m so to us; but now, in the division of the 5kingdom, it ap2ears not which of the Dukes he values most, for 5equalities are so weigh'd that curiosity in neither can make 5choice of either's moiety. 2Kent. Is not this your son, my lord? 2Glou. His bre2ding, sir, hath be2n at my charge. I have so often 5blush'd to acknowledge him that now I am braz'd to't. 2Kent. I can2ot conceive you. 2Glou. Sir, this young fel2ow's mother could; whereupon she grew 5round-womb'd, and had inde2d, sir, a son for her cradle ere she 5had a husband for her bed. Do you smel2 a fault? 2Kent. I can2ot wish the fault undone, the is2ue of it being so 5proper. 2Glou. But I have, sir, a son by order of law, some year elder than 5this, who yet is no dearer in my ac2ount. Though this knave came 5something saucily into the world before he was sent for, yet was 7his mother fair, there was go2d sport at his making, and the 5whoreson must be acknowledged.- Do you know this noble gentleman, 5Edmund? 2Edm. [comes forward] No, my lord. 2Glou. My Lord of Kent. Remember him hereafter as my honourable 5friend. 2Edm. My services to your lordship. 2Kent. I must love you, and sue to know you bet2er. 2Edm. Sir, I shal2 study deserving. 2Glou. He hath be2n out nine years, and away he shal2 again. 49Sound a sen2et. 5The King is coming. 6Enter one bearing a coronet; then Lear; then the Dukes of 6Albany and Cornwal2; next, Goneril, Regan, Cordelia, with 30Fol2owers. 2Lear. At2end the lords of France and Burgundy, Gloucester. 2Glou. I shal2, my liege. 33Exeunt [Gloucester and Edmund]. 2Lear. Meantime we shal2 expres2 our darker purpose. 5Give me the map there. Know we have divided 7In thre2 our kingdom; and 'tis our fast intent 5To shake al2 cares and busines2 from our age, 5Confer2ing them on younger strengths while we 5Unburthen'd crawl toward death. Our son of Cornwal2, 5And you, our no les2 loving son of Albany, 5We have this hour a constant wil2 to publish 5Our daughters' several dowers, that future strife 5May be prevented now. The princes, France and Burgundy, 5Great rivals in our youngest daughter's love, 5Long in our court have made their amorous sojourn, 5And here are to be answer'd. Tel2 me, my daughters 5(Since now we wil2 divest us both of rule, 5Interest of ter2itory, cares of state), 5Which of you shal2 we say doth love us most? 5That we our largest bounty may extend 5Where nature doth with merit chal2enge. Goneril, 5Our eldest-born, speak first. 2Gon. Sir, I love you more than words can wield the mat2er; 5Dearer than eyesight, space, and liberty; 5Beyond what can be valued, rich or rare; 7No les2 than life, with grace, health, beauty, honour; 5As much as child e'er lov'd, or father found; 5A love that makes breath po2r, and spe2ch unable. 5Beyond al2 man2er of so much I love you. 2Cor. [aside] What shal2 Cordelia speak? Love, and be silent. 2Lear. Of al2 these bounds, even from this line to this, 5With shadowy forests and with champains rich'd, 5With plenteous rivers and wide-skirted meads, 5We make the2 lady. To thine and Albany's is2ue 5Be this perpetual.- What says our second daughter, 5Our dearest Regan, wife to Cornwal2? Speak. 2Reg. Sir, I am made 5Of the selfsame metal that my sister is, 5And prize me at her worth. In my true heart 5I find she names my very de2d of love; 5Only she comes to2 short, that I profes2 5Myself an enemy to al2 other joys 5Which the most precious square of sense pos2es2es, 5And find I am alone felicitate 5In your dear Highnes2' love. 4Cor. [aside] Then po2r Cordelia! 5And yet not so; since I am sure my love's 5More richer than my tongue. 2Lear. To the2 and thine hereditary ever 5Remain this ample third of our fair kingdom, 5No les2 in space, validity, and pleasure 5Than that confer2'd on Goneril.- Now, our joy, 5Although the last, not least; to whose young love 5The vines of France and milk of Burgundy 5Strive to be interest; what can you say to draw 5A third more opulent than your sisters? Speak. 2Cor. Nothing, my lord. 2Lear. Nothing? 2Cor. Nothing. 2Lear. Nothing can come of nothing. Speak again. 2Cor. Unhap2y that I am, I can2ot heave 5My heart into my mouth. I love your Majesty 5Ac2ording to my bond; no more nor les2. 2Lear. How, how, Cordelia? Mend your spe2ch a lit2le, 5Lest it may mar your fortunes. 4Cor. Go2d my lord, 5You have begot me, bred me, lov'd me; I 5Return those duties back as are right fit, 5Obey you, love you, and most honour you. 5Why have my sisters husbands, if they say 5They love you al2? Haply, when I shal2 wed, 5That lord whose hand must take my plight shal2 car2y 5Half my love with him, half my care and duty. 5Sure I shal2 never mar2y like my sisters, 5To love my father al2. 2Lear. But goes thy heart with this? 2Cor. Ay, go2d my lord. 2Lear. So young, and so untender? 2Cor. So young, my lord, and true. 2Lear. Let it be so! thy truth then be thy dower! 5For, by the sacred radiance of the sun, 5The mysteries of Hecate and the night; 5By al2 the operation of the orbs 5From whom we do exist and cease to be; 5Here I disclaim al2 my paternal care, 7Propinquity and property of blo2d, 5And as a stranger to my heart and me 5Hold the2 from this for ever. The barbarous Scythian, 5Or he that makes his generation mes2es 5To gorge his ap2etite, shal2 to my bosom 5Be as wel2 neighbour'd, pitied, and reliev'd, 5As thou my sometime daughter. 2Kent. Go2d my liege- 2Lear. Peace, Kent! 5Come not betwe2n the dragon and his wrath. 5I lov'd her most, and thought to set my rest 5On her kind nursery.- Hence and avoid my sight!- 5So be my grave my peace as here I give 5Her father's heart from her! Cal2 France! Who stirs? 5Cal2 Burgundy! Cornwal2 and Albany, 5With my two daughters' dowers digest this third; 5Let pride, which she cal2s plain2es2, mar2y her. 5I do invest you jointly in my power, 5Pre2minence, and al2 the large ef2ects 5That tro2p with majesty. Ourself, by monthly course, 7With reservation of an hundred knights, 5By you to be sustain'd, shal2 our abode 5Make with you by due turns. Only we stil2 retain 5The name, and al2 th' ad2itions to a king. The sway, 5Revenue, execution of the rest, 5Beloved sons, be yours; which to confirm, 5This coronet part betwixt you. 2Kent. Royal Lear, 5Whom I have ever honour'd as my king, 5Lov'd as my father, as my master fol2ow'd, 5As my great patron thought on in my prayers- 2Lear. The bow is bent and drawn; make from the shaft. 2Kent. Let it fal2 rather, though the fork invade 5The region of my heart! Be Kent unman2erly 5When Lear is mad. What wouldst thou do, old man? 5Think'st thou that duty shal2 have dread to speak 5When power to flat2ery bows? To plain2es2 honour's bound 5When majesty fal2s to fol2y. Reverse thy do2m; 5And in thy best consideration check 5This hideous rashnes2. My life I never held but as a pawn 5To wage against thine enemies; nor fear to lose it, 5Thy safety being the motive. 2Lear. Out of my sight! 2Kent. Se2 bet2er, Lear, and let me stil2 remain 5The true blank of thine eye. 2Lear. Now by Apol2o- 2Kent. Now by Apol2o, King, 5Thou swear'st thy gods in vain. 2Lear. O vas2al! miscreant! 35[Lays his hand on his sword.] 2Alb., Corn. Dear sir, forbear! 2Kent. Do! 5Kil2 thy physician, and the fe2 bestow 5Upon the foul disease. Revoke thy gift, 5Or, whilst I can vent clamour from my throat, 7I'l2 tel2 the2 thou dost evil. 2Lear. Hear me, recreant! 5On thine al2egiance, hear me! 5Since thou hast sought to make us break our vow- 5Which we durst never yet- and with strain'd pride 5To come betwe2n our sentence and our power,- 5Which nor our nature nor our place can bear,- 5Our potency made go2d, take thy reward. 5Five days we do al2ot the2 for provision 5To shield the2 from diseases of the world, 5And on the sixth to turn thy hated back 5Upon our kingdom. If, on the tenth day fol2owing, 5Thy banish'd trunk be found in our dominions, 5The moment is thy death. Away! By Jupiter, 5This shal2 not be revok'd. 2Kent. Fare the2 wel2, King. Enter Gloucester, with France and Burgundy; At2endants. 2Glou. Here's France and Burgundy, my noble lord. 2Lear. My Lord of Burgundy, 5We first ad2res2 toward you, who with this king 5Hath rival2'd for our daughter. What in the least 5Wil2 you require in present dower with her, 5Or cease your quest of love? 2Bur. Most royal Majesty, 5I crave no more than hath your Highnes2 of2er'd, 5Nor wil2 you tender les2. 2Lear. Right noble Burgundy, 5When she was dear to us, we did hold her so; 5But now her price is fal2'n. Sir, there she stands. 5If aught within that lit2le se2ming substance, 5Or al2 of it, with our displeasure piec'd, 7And nothing more, may fitly like your Grace, 5She's there, and she is yours. 2Bur. I know no answer. 2Lear. Wil2 you, with those infirmities she owes, 5Unfriended, new adopted to our hate, 5Dow'r'd with our curse, and stranger'd with our oath, 5Take her, or leave her? 2Bur. Pardon me, royal sir. 5Election makes not up on such conditions. 2Lear. Then leave her, sir; for, by the pow'r that made me, 5I tel2 you al2 her wealth. [To France] For you, great King, 5I would not from your love make such a stray 5To match you where I hate; therefore bese2ch you 5T' avert your liking a more worthier way 5Than on a wretch whom nature is asham'd 5Almost t' acknowledge hers. 2France. This is most strange, 5That she that even but now was your best object, 5The argument of your praise, balm of your age, 5Most best, most dearest, should in this trice of time 7Com2it a thing so monstrous to dismantle 5So many folds of favour. Sure her of2ence 5Must be of such un2atural degre2 5That monsters it, or your fore-vouch'd af2ection 5Fal2'n into taint; which to believe of her 5Must be a faith that reason without miracle 5Should never plant in me. 2Cor. I yet bese2ch your Majesty, 5If for I want that glib and oily art 5To speak and purpose not, since what I wel2 intend, 5I'l2 do't before I speak- that you make known 5It is no vicious blot, murther, or foulnes2, 5No unchaste action or dishonoured step, 5That hath depriv'd me of your grace and favour; 5But even for want of that for which I am richer- 5A stil2-soliciting eye, and such a tongue 5As I am glad I have not, though not to have it 5Hath lost me in your liking. 2Lear. Bet2er thou 5Hadst not be2n born than not t' have pleas'd me bet2er. 4France. Is it but this- a tardines2 in nature 5Which often leaves the history unspoke 5That it intends to do? My Lord of Burgundy, 5What say you to the lady? Love's not love 5When it is mingled with regards that stands 5Alo2f from th' entire point. Wil2 you have her? 5She is herself a dowry. 2Bur. Royal Lear, 5Give but that portion which yourself propos'd, 5And here I take Cordelia by the hand, 5Duches2 of Burgundy. 2Lear. Nothing! I have sworn; I am firm. 2Bur. I am sor2y then you have so lost a father 5That you must lose a husband. 2Cor. Peace be with Burgundy! 5Since that respects of fortune are his love, 5I shal2 not be his wife. 2France. Fairest Cordelia, that art most rich, being po2r; 5Most choice, forsaken; and most lov'd, despis'd! 5The2 and thy virtues here I seize upon. 7Be it lawful I take up what's cast away. 5Gods, gods! 'tis strange that from their cold'st neglect 5My love should kindle to inflam'd respect. 5Thy dow'rles2 daughter, King, thrown to my chance, 5Is que2n of us, of ours, and our fair France. 5Not al2 the dukes in wat'rish Burgundy 5Can buy this unpriz'd precious maid of me. 5Bid them farewel2, Cordelia, though unkind. 5Thou losest here, a bet2er where to find. 2Lear. Thou hast her, France; let her be thine; for we 5Have no such daughter, nor shal2 ever se2 5That face of hers again. Therefore be gone 5Without our grace, our love, our benison. 5Come, noble Burgundy. 13Flourish. Exeunt Lear, Burgundy, [Cornwal2, Albany, 36Gloucester, and At2endants]. 2France. He always lov'd our 7sister most, and with what po2r judgment he hath now cast her 5of2 ap2ears to2 gros2ly. 2Reg. 'Tis the infirmity of his age; yet he hath ever but slenderly 5known himself. 2Gon. Thou, Nature, art my god2es2; to thy law 5My services are bound. Wherefore should I 5Stand in the plague of custom, and permit 5The curiosity of nations to deprive me, 5For that I am some twelve or fourte2n mo2nshines 5Lag of a brother? This vil2ain of mine comes under the 5prediction; there's son against father: the King fal2s from bias 5of nature; there's father against child. We have se2n the best 5of our time. This is the excel2ent fop2ery of the world, that, when we are 5sick in fortune, often the surfeit of our own behaviour, we make 5guilty of our disasters the sun, the mo2n, and the stars; as if 5we were vil2ains on neces2ity; fo2ls by heavenly compulsion; 5knaves, thieves, and treachers by spherical pre-dominance; 5drunkards, liars, and adulterers by an enforc'd obedience of 5planetary influence; and al2 that we are evil in, by a divine 5thrusting on. An admirable evasion of whore-master man, to lay 5his goatish disposition to the charge of a star! My father 5compounded with my mother under the Dragon's Tail, and my 5nativity was under Ursa Major, so that it fol2ows I am rough and 7lecherous. Fut! My lord, I am guiltles2, as I am ignorant 5Of what hath mov'd you. 2Lear. It may be so, my lord. 5Hear, Nature, hear! dear god2es2, hear! 5Suspend thy purpose, if thou didst intend 5To make this creature fruitful. 5Into her womb convey sterility; 5Dry up in her the organs of increase; 5And from her derogate body never spring 5A babe to honour her! If she must te2m, 7Create her child of sple2n, that it may live 5And be a thwart disnatur'd torment to her. 5Let it stamp wrinkles in her brow of youth, 5With cadent tears fret chan2els in her che2ks, 5Turn al2 her mother's pains and benefits 5To laughter and contempt, that she may fe2l 5How sharper than a serpent's to2th it is 5To have a thankles2 child! Away, away! 16Exit. 2Alb. Now, gods that we adore, whereof comes this? 2Gon. Never af2lict yourself to know the cause; 5But let his disposition have that scope 5That dotage gives it. 29Enter Lear. 2Lear. What, fifty of my fol2owers at a clap? 5Within a fortnight? 2Alb. What's the mat2er, sir? 2Lear. I'l2 tel2 the2. [To Goneril] Life and death! I am asham'd 5That thou hast power to shake my manho2d thus; 7That these hot tears, which break from me perforce, 5Should make the2 worth them. Blasts and fogs upon the2! 5Th' untented woundings of a father's curse 5Pierce every sense about the2!- Old fond eyes, 5Bewe2p this cause again, I'l2 pluck ye out, 5And cast you, with the waters that you lose, 5To temper clay. Yea, is it come to this? 5Let it be so. Yet have I left a daughter, 5Who I am sure is kind and comfortable. 5When she shal2 hear this of the2, with her nails 5She'l2 flay thy wolvish visage. Thou shalt find 5That I'l2 resume the shape which thou dost think 5I have cast of2 for ever; thou shalt, I war2ant the2. 28Exeunt [Lear, Kent, and At2endants]. 2Gon. Do you mark that, my lord? 2Alb. I can2ot be so partial, Goneril, 5To the great love I bear you - 2Gon. Pray you, content.- What, Oswald, ho! 5[To the Fo2l] You, sir, more knave than fo2l, after your master! 2Fo2l. Nuncle Lear, nuncle Lear, tar2y! Take the fo2l with the2. 12A fox when one has caught her, 10And such a daughter, 10Should sure to the slaughter, 10If my cap would buy a halter. 10So the fo2l fol2ows after. 23Exit. 2Gon. This man hath had go2d counsel! A hundred knights? 5'Tis politic and safe to let him ke2p 5At point a hundred knights; yes, that on every dream, 5Each buz2, each fancy, each complaint, dislike, 5He may enguard his dotage with their pow'rs 5And hold our lives in mercy.- Oswald, I say! 2Alb. Wel2, you may fear to2 far. 2Gon. Safer than trust to2 far. 5Let me stil2 take away the harms I fear, 5Not fear stil2 to be taken. I know his heart. 5What he hath ut2er'd I have writ my sister. 5If she sustain him and his hundred knights, 5When I have show'd th' unfitnes2- 23Enter [Oswald the] Steward. 5How now, Oswald? 5What, have you writ that let2er to my sister? 2Osw. Yes, madam. 2Gon. Take you some company, and away to horse! 5Inform her ful2 of my particular fear, 5And thereto ad2 such reasons of your own 5As may compact it more. Get you gone, 5And hasten your return. [Exit Oswald.] No, no, my lord! 5This milky gentlenes2 and course of yours, 5Though I condemn it not, yet, under pardon, 5You are much more at task for want of wisdom 5Than prais'd for harmful mildnes2. 2Alb. How far your eyes may pierce I can2ot tel2. 5Striving to bet2er, oft we mar what's wel2. 2Gon. Nay then- 2Alb. Wel2, wel2; th' event. 28Exeunt.Scene V.Court before the Duke of Albany's Palace.Enter Lear, Kent, and Fo2l. 2Lear. Go you before to Gloucester with these let2ers. Acquaint my 5daughter no further with anything you know than comes from her 5demand out of the let2er. If your diligence be not spe2dy, I 5shal2 be there afore you. 2Kent. I wil2 not sle2p, my lord, til2 I have delivered your let2er.Exit. 2Fo2l. If a man's brains were in's he2ls, were't not in danger of 5kibes? 2Lear. Ay, boy. 2Fo2l. Then I prithe2 be mer2y. Thy wit shal2 ne'er go slip-shod. 2Lear. Ha, ha, ha! 2Fo2l. Shalt se2 thy other daughter wil2 use the2 kindly; for though 5she's as like this as a crab's like an ap2le, yet I can tel2 5what I can tel2. 2Lear. What canst tel2, boy? 2Fo2l. She'l2 taste as like this as a crab does to a crab. Thou 5canst tel2 why one's nose stands i' th' mid2le on's face? 4Lear. No. 2Fo2l. Why, to ke2p one's eyes of either side's nose, that what a 5man can2ot smel2 out, 'a may spy into. 2Lear. I did her wrong. 2Fo2l. Canst tel2 how an oyster makes his shel2? 2Lear. No. 2Fo2l. Nor I neither; but I can tel2 why a snail has a house. 2Lear. Why? 2Fo2l. Why, to put's head in; not to give it away to his daughters, 5and leave his horns without a case. 2Lear. I wil2 forget my nature. So kind a father!- Be my horses 5ready? 2Fo2l. Thy as2es are gone about 'em. The reason why the seven stars 5are no moe than seven is a pret2y reason. 2Lear. If thou wert my fo2l, nuncle, I'ld have the2 beaten for being 5old before thy time. 2Lear. How's that? 4Fo2l. Thou shouldst not have be2n old til2 thou hadst be2n wise. 2Lear. Scene I.A court within the Castle of the Earl of Gloucester.Enter [Edmund the] Bastard and Curan, me2ting. 2Edm. Save the2, Curan. 2Cur. And you, sir. I have be2n with your father, and given him 5notice that the Duke of Cornwal2 and Regan his Duches2 wil2 be 5here with him this night. 2Edm. How comes that? 2Cur. Nay, I know not. You have heard of the news abroad- I mean the 5whisper'd ones, for they are yet but ear-kis2ing arguments? 2Edm. Not I. Pray you, what are they? 2Cur. Have you heard of no likely wars toward 'twixt the two Dukes 5of Cornwal2 and Albany? 2Edm. Not a word. 2Cur. You may do, then, in time. Fare you wel2, sir. 6Exit. 2Edm. The Duke be here to-night? The bet2er! best! 5This weaves itself perforce into my busines2. 5My father hath set guard to take my brother; 5And I have one thing, of a queasy question, 5Which I must act. Briefnes2 and fortune, work! 7Brother, a word! Descend! Brother, I say! 29Enter Edgar. 5My father watches. O sir, fly this place! 5Intel2igence is given where you are hid. 5You have now the go2d advantage of the night. 5Have you not spoken 'gainst the Duke of Cornwal2? 5He's coming hither; now, i' th' night, i' th' haste, 5And Regan with him. Have you nothing said 5Upon his party 'gainst the Duke of Albany? 5Advise yourself. 2Edg. I am sure on't, not a word. 2Edm. I hear my father coming. Pardon me! 5In cun2ing I must draw my sword upon you. 5Draw, se2m to defend yourself; now quit you wel2.- 5Yield! Come before my father. Light, ho, here! 5Fly, brother.- Torches, torches!- So farewel2. 53Exit Edgar. 5Some blo2d drawn on me would beget opinion 7Of my more fierce endeavour. [Stabs his arm.] I have se2n 8drunkards 5Do more than this in sport.- Father, father!- 5Stop, stop! No help? 13Enter Gloucester, and Servants with torches. 2Glou. Now, Edmund, where's the vil2ain? 2Edm. Here sto2d he in the dark, his sharp sword out, 5Mumbling of wicked charms, conjuring the mo2n 5To stand 's auspicious mistres2. 2Glou. But where is he? 2Edm. Lo2k, sir, I ble2d. 2Glou. Where is the vil2ain, Edmund? 2Edm. Fled this way, sir. When by no means he could- 2Glou. Pursue him, ho! Go after. 8[Exeunt some Servants]. 5By no means what? 2Edm. Persuade me to the murther of your lordship; 5But that I told him the revenging gods 5'Gainst par2icides did al2 their thunders bend; 7Spoke with how manifold and strong a bond 5The child was bound to th' father- sir, in fine, 5Se2ing how loathly op2osite I sto2d 5To his un2atural purpose, in fel2 motion 5With his prepared sword he charges home 5My unprovided body, lanch'd mine arm; 5But when he saw my best alarum'd spirits, 5Bold in the quar2el's right, rous'd to th' encounter, 5Or whether gasted by the noise I made, 5Ful2 sud2enly he fled. 2Glou. Let him fly far. 5Not in this land shal2 he remain uncaught; 5And found- dispatch. The noble Duke my master, 5My worthy arch and patron, comes to-night. 5By his authority I wil2 proclaim it 5That he which find, him shal2 deserve our thanks, 5Bringing the murderous caitif2 to the stake; 5He that conceals him, death. 2Edm. When I dis2uaded him from his intent 5And found him pight to do it, with curst spe2ch 7I threaten'd to discover him. He replied, 5'Thou unpos2es2ing bastard, dost thou think, 5If I would stand against the2, would the reposal 5Of any trust, virtue, or worth in the2 5Make thy words faith'd? No. What I should deny 5(As this I would; ay, though thou didst produce 5My very character), I'ld turn it al2 5To thy sug2estion, plot, and damned practice; 5And thou must make a dul2ard of the world, 5If they not thought the profits of my death 5Were very pregnant and potential spurs 5To make the2 se2k it.' 2Glou. Strong and fast'ned vil2ain! 5Would he deny his let2er? I never got him. 50Tucket within. 5Hark, the Duke's trumpets! I know not why he comes. 5Al2 ports I'l2 bar; the vil2ain shal2 not scape; 5The Duke must grant me that. Besides, his picture 5I wil2 send far and near, that al2 the kingdom 5May have due note of him, and of my land, 7Loyal and natural boy, I'l2 work the means 5To make the2 capable. 16Enter Cornwal2, Regan, and At2endants. 2Corn. How now, my noble friend? Since I came hither 5(Which I can cal2 but now) I have heard strange news. 2Reg. If it be true, al2 vengeance comes to2 short 5Which can pursue th' of2ender. How dost, my lord? 2Glou. O madam, my old heart is crack'd, it's crack'd! 2Reg. What, did my father's godson se2k your life? 5He whom my father nam'd? Your Edgar? 2Glou. O lady, lady, shame would have it hid! 2Reg. Was he not companion with the riotous knights 5That tend upon my father? 2Glou. I know not, madam. 'Tis to2 bad, to2 bad! 2Edm. Yes, madam, he was of that consort. 2Reg. No marvel then though he were il2 af2ected. 5'Tis they have put him on the old man's death, 5To have th' expense and waste of his revenues. 7I have this present evening from my sister 5Be2n wel2 inform'd of them, and with such cautions 5That, if they come to sojourn at my house, 5I'l2 not be there. 2Corn. Nor I, as2ure the2, Regan. 5Edmund, I hear that you have shown your father 5A childlike of2ice. 2Edm. 'Twas my duty, sir. 2Glou. He did bewray his practice, and receiv'd 5This hurt you se2, striving to ap2rehend him. 2Corn. Is he pursued? 2Glou. Ay, my go2d lord. 2Corn. If he be taken, he shal2 never more 5Be fear'd of doing harm. Make your own purpose, 5How in my strength you please. For you, Edmund, 5Whose virtue and obedience doth this instant 5So much com2end itself, you shal2 be ours. 5Natures of such de2p trust we shal2 much ne2d; 5You we first seize on. 2Edm. I shal2 serve you, sir, 7Truly, however else. 2Glou. For him I thank your Grace. 2Corn. You know not why we came to visit you- 2Reg. Thus out of season, threading dark-ey'd night. 5Oc2asions, noble Gloucester, of some poise, 5Wherein we must have use of your advice. 5Our father he hath writ, so hath our sister, 5Of dif2erences, which I best thought it fit 5To answer from our home. The several mes2engers 5From hence at2end dispatch. Our go2d old friend, 5Lay comforts to your bosom, and bestow 5Your ne2dful counsel to our busines2, 5Which craves the instant use. 2Glou. I serve you, madam. 5Your Graces are right welcome. 47Exeunt. Flourish.Scene I2.Before Gloucester's Castle.Enter Kent and [Oswald the] Steward, several2y. 2Osw. Go2d dawning to the2, friend. Art of this house? 2Kent. Ay. 2Osw. Where may we set our horses? 2Kent. I' th' mire. 2Osw. Prithe2, if thou lov'st me, tel2 me. 2Kent. I love the2 not. 2Osw. Why then, I care not for the2. 2Kent. If I had the2 in Lipsbury Pinfold, I would make the2 care for 5me. 2Osw. Why dost thou use me thus? I know the2 not. 2Kent. Fel2ow, I know the2. 2Osw. What dost thou know me for? 2Kent. A knave; a rascal; an eater of broken meats; a base, proud, 5shal2ow, beg2arly, thre2-suited, hundred-pound, filthy, 5worsted-stocking knave; a lily-liver'd, action-taking, whoreson, 5glas2-gazing, superserviceable, finical rogue; 5one-trunk-inheriting slave; one that wouldst be a bawd in way of 5go2d service, and art nothing but the composition of a knave, 7beg2ar, coward, pander, and the son and heir of a mongrel bitch; 5one whom I wil2 beat into clamorous whining, if thou deny the 5least syl2able of thy ad2ition. 2Osw. Why, what a monstrous fel2ow art thou, thus to rail on one 5that's neither known of the2 nor knows the2! 2Kent. What a brazen-fac'd varlet art thou, to deny thou knowest me! 5Is it two days ago since I beat the2 and trip2'd up thy he2ls 5before the King? You cowardly 5rascal, nature disclaims in the2; a tailor made the2. 2Corn. Thou art a strange fel2ow. A tailor make a man? 2Kent. Ay, a tailor, sir. A stonecut2er or a painter could not have 5made him so il2, though he had be2n but two hours at the trade. 2Corn. Speak yet, how grew your quar2el? 4Osw. This ancient ruf2ian, sir, whose life I have spar'd 5At suit of his grey beard- 2Kent. Thou whoreson zed! thou un2eces2ary let2er! That such a slave as this should wear a sword, 5Who wears no honesty. Such smiling rogues as these, 5Like rats, oft bite the holy cords atwain 5Which are to2 intrinse t' unlo2se; smo2th every pas2ion 5That in the natures of their lords rebel, 5Bring oil to fire, snow to their colder mo2ds; 5Renege, af2irm, and turn their halcyon beaks 5With every gale and vary of their masters, 5Knowing naught (like dogs) but fol2owing. 5A plague upon your epileptic visage! 7Smile you my spe2ches, as I were a fo2l? 5Go2se, an I had you upon Sarum Plain, 5I'ld drive ye cackling home to Camelot. 2Corn. His countenance likes me not. 2Corn. No more perchance does mine, or his, or hers. 2Kent. Sir, 'tis my oc2upation to be plain. 5I have se2n bet2er faces in my time 5Than stands on any shoulder that I se2 5Before me at this instant. 2Corn. This is some fel2ow 5Who, having be2n prais'd for bluntnes2, doth af2ect 5A saucy roughnes2, and constrains the garb 5Quite from his nature. He can2ot flat2er, he! 5An honest mind and plain- he must speak truth! 5An they wil2 take it, so; if not, he's plain. 7These kind of knaves I know which in this plain2es2 5Harbour more craft and more cor2upter ends 5Than twenty sil2y-ducking observants 5That stretch their duties nicely. 2Kent. Sir, in go2d faith, in sincere verity, 5Under th' al2owance of your great aspect, 5Whose influence, like the wreath of radiant fire 5On flickering Phoebus' front- 2Corn. What mean'st by this? 2Kent. To go out of my dialect, which you discom2end so much. I 5know, sir, I am no flat2erer. He that beguil'd you in a plain 5ac2ent was a plain knave, which, for my part, I wil2 not be, 5though I should win your displeasure to entreat me to't. 2Corn. What was th' of2ence you gave him? 2Osw. I never gave him any. 5It pleas'd the King his master very late 5To strike at me, upon his misconstruction; 5When he, conjunct, and flat2ering his displeasure, 5Trip2'd me behind; being down, insulted, rail'd 5And put upon him such a deal of man 7That worthied him, got praises of the King 5For him at2empting who was self-subdu'd; 5And, in the fleshment of this dread exploit, 5Drew on me here again. 2Kent. None of these rogues and cowards 5But Ajax is their fo2l. 2Corn. Fetch forth the stocks! 5You stub2orn ancient knave, you reverent brag2art, 5We'l2 teach you- 2Kent. Sir, I am to2 old to learn. 5Cal2 not your stocks for me. Why, madam, if I were your father's dog, 5You should not use me so. 4Reg. Sir, being his knave, I wil2. 2Corn. This is a fel2ow of the selfsame colour 5Our sister speaks of. Come, bring away the stocks! 45Stocks brought out. 2Glou. Let me bese2ch your Grace not to do so. 5His fault is much, and the go2d King his master 5Wil2 check him for't. My sister may receive it much more worse, 5To have her gentleman abus'd, as2aulted, 5For fol2owing her af2airs. Put in his legs.- 36[Kent is put in the stocks.] 5Come, my go2d lord, away. 27Exeunt [al2 but Gloucester and Kent]. 2Glou. I am sor2y for the2, friend. 'Tis the Duke's pleasure, 7Whose disposition, al2 the world wel2 knows, 5Wil2 not be rub2'd nor stop2'd. I'l2 entreat for the2. 2Kent. Pray do not, sir. I have watch'd and travel2'd hard. 5Some time I shal2 sle2p out, the rest I'l2 whistle. 5A go2d man's fortune may grow out at he2ls. 5Give you go2d mor2ow! 2Glou. The Duke 's to blame in this; 'twil2 be il2 taken.Exit. 2Kent. Go2d King, that must ap2rove the com2on saw, 5Thou out of heaven's benediction com'st 5To the warm sun! 5Ap2roach, thou beacon to this under globe, 5That by thy comfortable beams I may 5Peruse this let2er. Nothing almost se2s miracles 5But misery. I know 'tis from Cordelia, 5Who hath most fortunately be2n inform'd 5Of my obscured course- and [reads] 'shal2 find time 5From this enormous state, se2king to give 5Los2es their remedies'- Al2 weary and o'erwatch'd, 5Take vantage, heavy eyes, not to behold 7This shameful lodging. 5Fortune, go2d night; smile once more, turn thy whe2l. 57Sle2ps.Scene I3.The open country.Enter Edgar. 2Edg. I heard myself proclaim'd, 5And by the hap2y hol2ow of a tre2 5Escap'd the hunt. No port is fre2, no place 5That guard and most unusual vigilance 5Does not at2end my taking. Whiles I may scape, 5I wil2 preserve myself; and am bethought 5To take the basest and most po2rest shape 5That ever penury, in contempt of man, 5Brought near to beast. My face I'l2 grime with filth, 5Blanket my loins, elf al2 my hair in knots, 5And with presented nakednes2 outface 5The winds and persecutions of the sky. 5The country gives me pro2f and precedent 5Of Bedlam beg2ars, who, with roaring voices, 5Strike in their numb'd and mortified bare arms 5Pins, wo2den pricks, nails, sprigs of rosemary; 5And with this hor2ible object, from low farms, 7Po2r pelting vil2ages, she2pcotes, and mil2s, 5Sometime with lunatic bans, sometime with prayers, 5Enforce their charity. 'Po2r Turlygod! po2r Tom!' 5That's something yet! Edgar I nothing am. 13Exit.Scene IV.Before Gloucester's Castle; Kent in the stocks.Enter Lear, Fo2l, and Gentleman. 2Lear. 'Tis strange that they should so depart from home, 5And not send back my mes2enger. 2Gent. As I learn'd, 5The night before there was no purpose in them 5Of this remove. 2Kent. Hail to the2, noble master! 2Lear. Ha! 5Mak'st thou this shame thy pastime? 2Kent. No, my lord. 2Fo2l. Ha, ha! lo2k! he wears cruel garters. Horses are tied by the 5head, dogs and bears by th' neck, monkeys by th' loins, and men 5by th' legs. When a man's over-lusty at legs, then he wears 5wo2den nether-stocks. 2Lear. What's he that hath so much thy place misto2k 5To set the2 here? 2Kent. It is both he and she- 5Your son and daughter. 4Lear. No. 2Kent. Yes. 2Lear. No, I say. 2Kent. I say yea. 2Lear. No, no, they would not! 2Kent. Yes, they have. 2Lear. By Jupiter, I swear no! 2Kent. By Juno, I swear ay! 2Lear. They durst not do't; 5They would not, could not do't. 'Tis worse than murther 5To do upon respect such violent outrage. 5Resolve me with al2 modest haste which way 5Thou mightst deserve or they impose this usage, 5Coming from us. 2Kent. My lord, when at their home 5I did com2end your Highnes2' let2ers to them, 5Ere I was risen from the place that show'd 5My duty kne2ling, came there a re2king post, 5Stew'd in his haste, half breathles2, panting forth 5From Goneril his mistres2 salutations; 7Deliver'd let2ers, spite of intermis2ion, 5Which presently they read; on whose contents, 5They sum2on'd up their meiny, straight to2k horse, 5Com2anded me to fol2ow and at2end 5The leisure of their answer, gave me cold lo2ks, 5And me2ting here the other mes2enger, 5Whose welcome I perceiv'd had poison'd mine- 5Being the very fel2ow which of late 5Display'd so saucily against your Highnes2- 5Having more man than wit about me, drew. 5He rais'd the house with loud and coward cries. 5Your son and daughter found this trespas2 worth 5The shame which here it suf2ers. 2Fo2l. Winter's not gone yet, if the wild ge2se fly that way. 10Fathers that wear rags 12Do make their children blind; 10But fathers that bear bags 12Shal2 se2 their children kind. 10Fortune, that ar2ant whore, 12Ne'er turns the key to th' po2r. 5But for al2 this, thou shalt have as many dolours for thy 5daughters as thou canst tel2 in a year. 2Lear. O, how this mother swel2s up toward my heart! 5Hysterica pas2io! Down, thou climbing sor2ow! 5Thy element's below! Where is this daughter? 2Kent. With the Earl, sir, here within. 2Lear. Fol2ow me not; 5Stay here. 44Exit. 2Gent. Made you no more of2ence but what you speak of? 2Kent. None. 5How chance the King comes with so smal2 a number? 2Fo2l. An thou hadst be2n set i' th' stocks for that question, 5thou'dst wel2 deserv'd it. 2Kent. Why, fo2l? 2Fo2l. We'l2 set the2 to scho2l to an ant, to teach the2 there's no 5labouring i' th' winter. Al2 that fol2ow their noses are led by 5their eyes but blind men, and there's not a nose among twenty 5but can smel2 him that's stinking. Let go thy hold when a great 7whe2l runs down a hil2, lest it break thy neck with fol2owing 5it; but the great one that goes upward, let him draw the2 after. 5When a wise man gives the2 bet2er counsel, give me mine again. I 5would have none but knaves fol2ow it, since a fo2l gives it. 10That sir which serves and se2ks for gain, 12And fol2ows but for form, 10Wil2 pack when it begins to rain 12And leave the2 in the storm. 10But I wil2 tar2y; the fo2l wil2 stay, 12And let the wise man fly. 10The knave turns fo2l that runs away; 12The fo2l no knave, perdy. 2Kent. Where learn'd you this, fo2l? 2Fo2l. Not i' th' stocks, fo2l. 22Enter Lear and Gloucester 2Lear. Deny to speak with me? They are sick? they are weary? 5They have travel2'd al2 the night? Mere fetches- 5The images of revolt and flying of2! 7Fetch me a bet2er answer. 2Glou. My dear lord, 5You know the fiery quality of the Duke, 5How unremovable and fix'd he is 5In his own course. 2Lear. Vengeance! plague! death! confusion! 5Fiery? What quality? Why, Gloucester, Gloucester, 5I'ld speak with the Duke of Cornwal2 and his wife. 2Glou. Wel2, my go2d lord, I have inform'd them so. 2Lear. Inform'd them? Dost thou understand me, man? 2Glou. Ay, my go2d lord. 2Lear. The King would speak with Cornwal2; the dear father 5Would with his daughter speak, com2ands her service. 5Are they inform'd of this? My breath and blo2d! 5Fiery? the fiery Duke? Tel2 the hot Duke that- 5No, but not yet! May be he is not wel2. 5Infirmity doth stil2 neglect al2 of2ice 5Whereto our health is bound. We are not ourselves 5When nature, being op2res2'd, com2ands the mind 5To suf2er with the body. I'l2 forbear; 7And am fal2en out with my more headier wil2, 5To take the indispos'd and sickly fit 5For the sound man.- Death on my state! Wherefore 5Should be sit here? This act persuades me 5That this remotion of the Duke and her 5Is practice only. Give me my servant forth. 5Go tel2 the Duke and 's wife I'ld speak with them- 5Now, presently. Bid them come forth and hear me, 5Or at their chamber do2r I'l2 beat the drum 5Til2 it cry sle2p to death. 2Glou. I would have al2 wel2 betwixt you. 17Exit. 2Lear. O me, my heart, my rising heart! But down! 2Fo2l. Cry to it, nuncle, as the cockney did to the e2ls when she 5put 'em i' th' paste alive. She knap2'd 'em o' th' coxcombs with 5a stick and cried 'Down, wantons, down!' 'Twas her brother that, 5in pure kindnes2 to his horse, but2ered his hay. 13Enter Cornwal2, Regan, Gloucester, Servants. 2Lear. Go2d mor2ow to you both. 4Corn. Hail to your Grace! 39Kent here set at liberty. 2Reg. I am glad to se2 your Highnes2. 2Lear. Regan, I think you are; I know what reason 5I have to think so. If thou shouldst not be glad, 5I would divorce me from thy mother's tomb, 5Sepulchring an adultres2. [To Kent] O, are you fre2? 5Some other time for that.- Beloved Regan, 5Thy sister's naught. I pray you, sir, take patience. I have hope 5You les2 know how to value her desert 5Than she to scant her duty. 2Lear. Say, how is that? 2Reg. I can2ot think my sister in the least 5Would fail her obligation. If, sir, perchance 5She have restrain'd the riots of your fol2owers, 7'Tis on such ground, and to such wholesome end, 5As clears her from al2 blame. 2Lear. My curses on her! 2Reg. O, sir, you are old! 5Nature in you stands on the very verge 5Of her confine. You should be rul'd, and led 5By some discretion that discerns your state 5Bet2er than you yourself. Therefore I pray you 5That to our sister you do make return; 5Say you have wrong'd her, sir. 2Lear. Ask her forgivenes2? 5Do you but mark how this becomes the house: 5'Dear daughter, I confes2 that I am old. 10[Kne2ls.] 5Age is un2eces2ary. On my kne2s I beg 5That you'l2 vouchsafe me raiment, bed, and fo2d.' 2Reg. Go2d sir, no more! These are unsightly tricks. 5Return you to my sister. 2Lear. [rises] Never, Regan! 5She hath abated me of half my train; 5Lo2k'd black upon me; struck me with her tongue, 7Most serpent-like, upon the very heart. 5Al2 the stor'd vengeances of heaven fal2 5On her ingrateful top! Strike her young bones, 5You taking airs, with lamenes2! 2Corn. Fie, sir, fie! 2Lear. You nimble lightnings, dart your blinding flames 5Into her scornful eyes! Infect her beauty, 5You fen-suck'd fogs, drawn by the pow'rful sun, 5To fal2 and blast her pride! 2Reg. O the blest gods! so wil2 you wish on me 5When the rash mo2d is on. 2Lear. Our basest beg2ars 5Are in the po2rest thing superfluous. 5Al2ow not nature more than nature ne2ds, 5Man's life is cheap as beast's. 'Tis best to give him way; he leads himself. 2Gon. My lord, entreat him by no means to stay. 2Glou. Alack, the night comes on, and the bleak winds 5Do sorely ruf2le. Scene I.A heath.Storm stil2. Enter Kent and a Gentleman at several do2rs. 2Kent. Who's there, besides foul weather? 2Gent. One minded like the weather, most unquietly. 2Kent. I know you. Where's the King? 2Gent. Contending with the fretful elements; 5Bids the wind blow the earth into the sea, 5Or swel2 the curled waters 'bove the main, 5That things might change or cease; tears his white hair, 5Which the impetuous blasts, with eyeles2 rage, 5Catch in their fury and make nothing of; 5Strives in his lit2le world of man to outscorn 5The to-and-fro-conflicting wind and rain. 5This night, wherein the cub-drawn bear would couch, 5The lion and the bel2y-pinched wolf 5Ke2p their fur dry, unbon2eted he runs, 5And bids what wil2 take al2. 2Kent. But who is with him? 2Gent. None but the fo2l, who labours to outjest 7His heart-struck injuries. 2Kent. Sir, I do know you, 5And dare upon the war2ant of my note 5Com2end a dear thing to you. There is division 5(Although as yet the face of it be cover'd 5With mutual cun2ing) 'twixt Albany and Cornwal2; 5Who have (as who have not, that their great stars 5Thron'd and set high?) servants, who se2m no les2, 5Which are to France the spies and speculations 5Intel2igent of our state. What hath be2n se2n, 5Either in snuf2s and packings of the Dukes, 5Or the hard rein which both of them have borne 5Against the old kind King, or something de2per, 5Whereof, perchance, these are but furnishings- 5But, true it is, from France there comes a power 5Into this scat2ered kingdom, who already, 5Wise in our negligence, have secret fe2t 5In some of our best ports and are at point 5To show their open ban2er. Now to you: 5If on my credit you dare build so far 7To make your spe2d to Dover, you shal2 find 5Some that wil2 thank you, making just report 5Of how un2atural and bemad2ing sor2ow 5The King hath cause to plain. 5I am a gentleman of blo2d and bre2ding, 5And from some knowledge and as2urance of2er 5This of2ice to you. 2Gent. I wil2 talk further with you. 2Kent. No, do not. 5For confirmation that I am much more 5Than my out-wal2, open this purse and take 5What it contains. If you shal2 se2 Cordelia 5(As fear not but you shal2), show her this ring, 5And she wil2 tel2 you who your fel2ow is 5That yet you do not know. Fie on this storm! 5I wil2 go se2k the King. 2Gent. Give me your hand. Have you no more to say? 2Kent. Few words, but, to ef2ect, more than al2 yet: 5That, when we have found the King (in which your pain 5That way, I'l2 this), he that first lights on him 7Hol2a the other. 45Exeunt [several2y].Scene I2.Another part of the heath.Storm stil2. Enter Lear and Fo2l. 2Lear. Blow, winds, and crack your che2ks! rage! blow! 5You cataracts and hur2icanoes, spout 5Til2 you have drench'd our ste2ples, drown'd the cocks! 5You sulph'rous and thought-executing fires, 5Vaunt-couriers to oak-cleaving thunderbolts, 5Singe my white head! And thou, al2-shaking thunder, 5Strike flat the thick rotundity o' th' world, 5Crack Nature's moulds, al2 germains spil2 at once, 5That makes ingrateful man! 2Fo2l. O nuncle, court holy water in a dry house is bet2er than this 5rain water out o' do2r. Go2d nuncle, in, and ask thy daughters 5bles2ing! Here's a night pities nether wise men nor fo2ls. 2Lear. Rumble thy bel2yful! Spit, fire! spout, rain! 5Nor rain, wind, thunder, fire are my daughters. 5I tax not you, you elements, with unkindnes2. 5I never gave you kingdom, cal2'd you children, 5You owe me no subscription. Then let fal2 7Your hor2ible pleasure. Here I stand your slave, 5A po2r, infirm, weak, and despis'd old man. 5But yet I cal2 you servile ministers, 5That wil2 with two pernicious daughters join 5Your high-engender'd bat2les 'gainst a head 5So old and white as this! O! O! 'tis foul! 2Fo2l. He that has a house to put 's head in has a go2d head-piece. 10The codpiece that wil2 house 12Before the head has any, 10The head and he shal2 louse: 12So beg2ars mar2y many. 10The man that makes his toe 12What he his heart should make 10Shal2 of a corn cry woe, 12And turn his sle2p to wake. 5For there was never yet fair woman but she made mouths in a 5glas2. 29Enter Kent. 4Lear. No, I wil2 be the pat2ern of al2 patience; 5I wil2 say nothing. 2Kent. Who's there? 2Fo2l. Mar2y, here's grace and a codpiece; that's a wise man and a 5fo2l. 2Kent. Alas, sir, are you here? Things that love night 5Love not such nights as these. The wrathful skies 5Gal2ow the very wanderers of the dark 5And make them ke2p their caves. Since I was man, 5Such she2ts of fire, such bursts of hor2id thunder, 5Such groans of roaring wind and rain, I never 5Remember to have heard. Man's nature can2ot car2y 5Th' af2liction nor the fear. 2Lear. Let the great gods, 5That ke2p this dreadful pud2er o'er our heads, 5Find out their enemies now. Tremble, thou wretch, 5That hast within the2 undivulged crimes 5Unwhip2'd of justice. Hide the2, thou blo2dy hand; 5Thou perjur'd, and thou simular man of virtue 5That art incestuous. Caitif2, in pieces shake 7That under covert and convenient se2ming 5Hast practis'd on man's life. Close pent-up guilts, 5Rive your concealing continents, and cry 5These dreadful sum2oners grace. I am a man 5More sin2'd against than sin2ing. 2Kent. Alack, bareheaded? 5Gracious my lord, hard by here is a hovel; 5Some friendship wil2 it lend you 'gainst the tempest. 5Repose you there, whilst I to this hard house 5(More harder than the stones whereof 'tis rais'd, 5Which even but now, demanding after you, 5Denied me to come in) return, and force 5Their scanted courtesy. 2Lear. My wits begin to turn. 5Come on, my boy. How dost, my boy? Art cold? 5I am cold myself. Where is this straw, my fel2ow? 5The art of our neces2ities is strange, 5That can make vile things precious. Come, your hovel. 5Po2r fo2l and knave, I have one part in my heart 5That's sor2y yet for the2. 4Fo2l. [sings] 10He that has and a lit2le tiny wit- 12With hey, ho, the wind and the rain- 10Must make content with his fortunes fit, 13For the rain it raineth every day. 2Lear. True, my go2d boy. Come, bring us to this hovel. 41Exeunt [Lear and Kent]. 2Fo2l. This is a brave night to co2l a courtesan. I'l2 speak a 5prophecy ere I go: 10When priests are more in word than mat2er; 10When brewers mar their malt with water; 10When nobles are their tailors' tutors, 10No heretics burn'd, but wenches' suitors; 10When every case in law is right, 10No squire in debt nor no po2r knight; 10When slanders do not live in tongues, 10Nor cutpurses come not to throngs; 10When usurers tel2 their gold i' th' field, 12And bawds and whores do churches build: 10Then shal2 the realm of Albion 10Come to great confusion. 10Then comes the time, who lives to se2't, 10That going shal2 be us'd with fe2t. 5This prophecy Merlin shal2 make, for I live before his time.Exit.Scene I3.Gloucester's Castle.Enter Gloucester and Edmund. 2Glou. Alack, alack, Edmund, I like not this un2atural dealing! When 5I desir'd their leave that I might pity him, they to2k from me 5the use of mine own house, charg'd me on pain of perpetual 5displeasure neither to speak of him, entreat for him, nor any 5way sustain him. 2Edm. Most savage and un2atural! 2Glou. Go to; say you nothing. There is division betwixt the Dukes, 5and a worse mat2er than that. Though I 5die for't, as no les2 is threat'ned me, the King my old master 5must be relieved. There is some strange thing toward, Edmund. 5Pray you be careful. 34Exit. 4Edm. This courtesy, forbid the2, shal2 the Duke 5Instantly know, and of that let2er to2. 5This se2ms a fair deserving, and must draw me 5That which my father loses- no les2 than al2. 5The younger rises when the old doth fal2. 13Exit.Scene IV.The heath. Before a hovel.Storm stil2. Enter Lear, Kent, and Fo2l. 2Kent. Here is the place, my lord. Go2d my lord, enter. 5The tyran2y of the open night 's to2 rough 5For nature to endure. 2Lear. Let me alone. 2Kent. Go2d my lord, enter here. 2Lear. Wilt break my heart? 2Kent. I had rather break mine own. Go2d my lord, enter. 2Lear. Thou think'st 'tis much that this contentious storm 5Invades us to the skin. So 'tis to the2; 5But where the greater malady is fix'd, 5The les2er is scarce felt. Thou'dst shun a bear; 5But if thy flight lay toward the raging sea, 5Thou'dst me2t the bear i' th' mouth. When the mind's fre2, 5The body's delicate. The tempest in my mind 5Doth from my senses take al2 fe2ling else 5Save what beats there. Filial ingratitude! 5Is it not as this mouth should tear this hand 7For lifting fo2d to't? But I wil2 punish home! 5No, I wil2 we2p no more. In such a night 5'To shut me out! Pour on; I wil2 endure. 5In such a night as this! O Regan, Goneril! 5Your old kind father, whose frank heart gave al2! 5O, that way madnes2 lies; let me shun that! 5No more of that. 2Kent. Go2d my lord, enter here. 2Lear. Prithe2 go in thyself; se2k thine own ease. 5This tempest wil2 not give me leave to ponder 5On things would hurt me more. But I'l2 go in. 5[To the Fo2l] In, boy; go first.- You houseles2 poverty- 5Nay, get the2 in. I'l2 pray, and then I'l2 sle2p. 52Exit [Fo2l]. 5Po2r naked wretches, wheresoe'er you are, 5That bide the pelting of this pitiles2 storm, 5How shal2 your houseles2 heads and unfed sides, 5Your lo2p'd and window'd rag2ednes2, defend you 5From seasons such as these? [within] Fathom and half, fathom and half! Po2r Tom! 21Enter Fo2l [from the hovel]. 2Fo2l. Come not in here, nuncle, here's a spirit. Help me, help me! 2Kent. Give me thy hand. Who's there? 2Fo2l. A spirit, a spirit! He says his name's po2r Tom. 2Kent. What art thou that dost grumble there i' th' straw? 5Come forth. 17Enter Edgar [disguised as a madman]. 2Edg. Away! the foul fiend fol2ows me! Through the sharp hawthorn 5blows the cold wind. Humh! go to thy cold bed, and warm the2. 2Lear. Hast thou given al2 to thy two daughters, and art thou come 5to this? 2Edg. Who gives anything to po2r Tom? whom the foul fiend hath led 7through fire and through flame, through ford and whirlpo2l, o'er 5bog and quagmire; that hath laid knives under his pil2ow and 5halters in his pew, set ratsbane by his por2idge, made him proud 5of heart, to ride on a bay trot2ing horse over four-inch'd 5bridges, to course his own shadow for a traitor. Bles2 thy five 5wits! Tom 's acold. O, do de, do de, do de. Bles2 the2 from 5whirlwinds, star-blasting, and taking! Do po2r Tom some charity, 5whom the foul fiend vexes. There could I have him now- and there- 5and there again- and there! 52Storm stil2. 2Lear. What, have his daughters brought him to this pas2? 5Couldst thou save nothing? Didst thou give 'em al2? 2Fo2l. Nay, he reserv'd a blanket, else we had be2n al2 sham'd. 2Lear. Now al2 the plagues that in the pendulous air 5Hang fated o'er men's faults light on thy daughters! 2Kent. He hath no daughters, sir. 2Lear. Death, traitor! nothing could have subdu'd nature 5To such a lownes2 but his unkind daughters. 5Is it the fashion that discarded fathers 5Should have thus lit2le mercy on their flesh? 7Judicious punishment! 'Twas this flesh begot 5Those pelican daughters. 2Edg. Pil2icock sat on Pil2icock's Hil2. 'Al2ow, 'al2ow, lo2, lo2! 2Fo2l. This cold night wil2 turn us al2 to fo2ls and madmen. 2Edg. Take he2d o' th' foul fiend; obey thy parents: ke2p thy word 5justly; swear not; com2it not with man's sworn spouse; set not 5thy swe2t heart on proud ar2ay. Tom 's acold. 2Lear. What hast thou be2n? 2Edg. A servingman, proud in heart and mind; that curl'd my hair, 5wore gloves in my cap; serv'd the lust of my mistres2' heart and 5did the act of darknes2 with her; swore as many oaths as I spake 5words, and broke them in the swe2t face of heaven; one that 5slept in the contriving of lust, and wak'd to do it. Wine lov'd 5I de2ply, dice dearly; and in woman out-paramour'd the Turk. 5False of heart, light of ear, blo2dy of hand; hog in sloth, fox 5in stealth, wolf in gre2dines2, dog in madnes2, lion in prey. 5Let not the creaking of shoes nor the rustling of silks betray 5thy po2r heart to woman. Ke2p thy fo2t out of brothel, thy hand 5out of placket, thy pen from lender's bo2k, and defy the foul 5fiend. Stil2 through the hawthorn blows the cold wind; says 7su2m, mun, hey, no, non2y. Dolphin my boy, my boy, ses2a! let 5him trot by. 52Storm stil2. 2Lear. Why, thou wert bet2er in thy grave than to answer with thy 5uncover'd body this extremity of the skies. Scene I.The heath.Enter Edgar. 2Edg. Yet bet2er thus, and known to be contemn'd, 5Than stil2 contemn'd and flat2er'd. To be worst, 5The lowest and most dejected thing of fortune, 5Stands stil2 in esperance, lives not in fear. 5The lamentable change is from the best; 5The worst returns to laughter. Welcome then, 5Thou unsubstantial air that I embrace! 5The wretch that thou hast blown unto the worst 5Owes nothing to thy blasts. 17Enter Gloucester, led by an Old Man. 5But who comes here? 5My father, po2rly led? World, world, O world! 5But that thy strange mutations make us hate the2, 5Life would not yield to age. 2Old Man. O my go2d lord, 7I have be2n your tenant, and your father's tenant, 5These fourscore years. 2Glou. Away, get the2 away! Go2d friend, be gone. 5Thy comforts can do me no go2d at al2; 5The2 they may hurt. 2Old Man. You can2ot se2 your way. 2Glou. I have no way, and therefore want no eyes; 5I stumbled when I saw. Ful2 oft 'tis se2n 5Our means secure us, and our mere defects 5Prove our com2odities. Ah dear son Edgar, 5The fo2d of thy abused father's wrath! 5Might I but live to se2 the2 in my touch, 5I'ld say I had eyes again! 2Old Man. How now? Who's there? 2Edg. [aside] O gods! Who is't can say 'I am at the worst'? 5I am worse than e'er I was. 2Old Man. 'Tis po2r mad Tom. 2Edg. [aside] And worse I may be yet. The worst is not 5So long as we can say 'This is the worst.' 2Old Man. Fel2ow, where goest? 4Glou. Is it a beg2arman? 2Old Man. Madman and beg2ar to2. 2Glou. He has some reason, else he could not beg. 5I' th' last night's storm I such a fel2ow saw, 5Which made me think a man a worm. My son 5Came then into my mind, and yet my mind 5Was then scarce friends with him. I have heard more since. 5As flies to wanton boys are we to th' gods. 5They kil2 us for their sport. 2Edg. Five fiends have be2n in po2r Tom at once: of 5lust, as Obidicut; Hob2ididence, prince of dumbnes2; Mahu, of 5stealing; Modo, of murder; Flib2ertigib2et, of mop2ing and 5mowing, who since pos2es2es chambermaids and waiting women.
