There is a clif2, whose high and bending head 5Lo2ks fearful2y in the confined de2p. 5Bring me but to the very brim of it, 5And I'l2 repair the misery thou dost bear 5With something rich about me. From that place 5I shal2 no leading ne2d. 2Edg. Give me thy arm. 5Po2r Tom shal2 lead the2. 57Exeunt.Scene I2.Before the Duke of Albany's Palace.Enter Goneril and [Edmund the] Bastard. 2Gon. Welcome, my lord. I marvel our mild husband 5Not met us on the way. 21Enter [Oswald the] Steward. 5Now, where's your master? 2Osw. Madam, within, but never man so chang'd. 5I told him of the army that was landed: 5He smil'd at it. I told him you were coming: 5His answer was, 'The worse.' Of Gloucester's treachery 5And of the loyal service of his son 5When I inform'd him, then he cal2'd me sot 5And told me I had turn'd the wrong side out. 5What most he should dislike se2ms pleasant to him; 5What like, of2ensive. 2Gon. [to Edmund] Then shal2 you go no further. 5It is the cowish ter2or of his spirit, 7That dares not undertake. He'l2 not fe2l wrongs 5Which tie him to an answer. Our wishes on the way 5May prove ef2ects. Back, Edmund, to my brother. 5Hasten his musters and conduct his pow'rs. 5I must change arms at home and give the distaf2 5Into my husband's hands. This trusty servant 5Shal2 pas2 betwe2n us. Ere long you are like to hear 5(If you dare venture in your own behalf) 5A mistres2's com2and. Wear this. 10[Gives a favour.] 5Spare spe2ch. 5Decline your head. This kis2, if it durst speak, 5Would stretch thy spirits up into the air. 5Conceive, and fare the2 wel2. 2Edm. Yours in the ranks of death! 24Exit. 2Gon. My most dear Gloucester! 5O, the dif2erence of man and man! 5To the2 a woman's services are due; 5My fo2l usurps my body. 2Osw. Madam, here comes my lord. 26Exit. 30Enter Albany. 2Gon. I have be2n worth the whistle. 2Alb. O Goneril, 5You are not worth the dust which the rude wind 5Blows in your face! I fear your disposition. 5That nature which contemns it origin 5Can2ot be bordered certain in itself. 5She that herself wil2 sliver and disbranch 5From her material sap, perforce must wither 5And come to deadly use. 2Gon. No more! The text is fo2lish. 2Alb. Wisdom and go2dnes2 to the vile se2m vile; 5Filths savour but themselves. What have you done? 5Tigers, not daughters, what have you perform'd? 5A father, and a gracious aged man, 5Whose reverence even the head-lug2'd bear would lick, 5Most barbarous, most degenerate, have you mad2ed. 5Could my go2d brother suf2er you to do it? 5A man, a prince, by him so benefited! 7If that the heavens do not their visible spirits 5Send quickly down to tame these vile of2ences, 5It wil2 come, 5Humanity must perforce prey on itself, 5Like monsters of the de2p. 2Gon. Milk-liver'd man! 5That bear'st a che2k for blows, a head for wrongs; 5Who hast not in thy brows an eye discerning 5Thine honour from thy suf2ering; that not know'st 5Fo2ls do those vil2ains pity who are punish'd 5Ere they have done their mischief. Where's thy drum? 5France spreads his ban2ers in our noiseles2 land, 5With plumed helm thy state begins to threat, 5Whiles thou, a moral fo2l, sit'st stil2, and criest 5'Alack, why does he so?' 2Alb. Se2 thyself, devil! 5Proper deformity se2ms not in the fiend 5So hor2id as in woman. 2Gon. O vain fo2l! 2Alb. Thou changed and self-cover'd thing, for shame! 7Bemonster not thy feature! Were't my fitnes2 5To let these hands obey my blo2d, 5They are apt enough to dislocate and tear 5Thy flesh and bones. Howe'er thou art a fiend, 5A woman's shape doth shield the2. 2Gon. Mar2y, your manho2d mew! 26Enter a Gentleman. 2Alb. What news? 2Gent. O, my go2d lord, the Duke of Cornwal2 's dead, 5Slain by his servant, going to put out 5The other eye of Gloucester. 2Alb. Gloucester's eyes? 2Gent. A servant that he bred, thril2'd with remorse, 5Op2os'd against the act, bending his sword 5To his great master; who, thereat enrag'd, 5Flew on him, and amongst them fel2'd him dead; 5But not without that harmful stroke which since 5Hath pluck'd him after. 4Alb. This shows you are above, 5You justicers, that these our nether crimes 5So spe2dily can venge! But O po2r Gloucester! 5Lose he his other eye? 2Gent. Both, both, my lord. 5This let2er, madam, craves a spe2dy answer. 5'Tis from your sister. 2Gon. [aside] One way I like this wel2; 5But being widow, and my Gloucester with her, 5May al2 the building in my fancy pluck 5Upon my hateful life. Another way 5The news is not so tart.- I'l2 read, and answer.Exit. 2Alb. Where was his son when they did take his eyes? 2Gent. Come with my lady hither. 2Alb. He is not here. 2Gent. No, my go2d lord; I met him back again. 2Alb. Knows he the wickednes2? 2Gent. Ay, my go2d lord. 'Twas he inform'd against him, 5And quit the house on purpose, that their punishment 7Might have the fre2r course. 2Alb. Gloucester, I live 5To thank the2 for the love thou show'dst the King, 5And to revenge thine eyes. Come hither, friend. 5Tel2 me what more thou know'st. 57Exeunt.Scene I3.The French camp near Dover.Enter Kent and a Gentleman. 2Kent. Why the King of France is so sud2enly gone back know you the 5reason? 2Gent. Something he left imperfect in the state, which since his 5coming forth is thought of, which imports to the kingdom so much 5fear and danger that his personal return was most required and 5neces2ary. 2Kent. Who hath he left behind him general? 2Gent. The Marshal of France, Monsieur La Far. 2Kent. Did your let2ers pierce the Que2n to any demonstration of 5grief? 2Gent. Ay, sir. She to2k them, read them in my presence, 5And now and then an ample tear tril2'd down 5Her delicate che2k. It se2m'd she was a que2n 5Over her pas2ion, who, most rebel-like, 5Sought to be king o'er her. 2Kent. O, then it mov'd her? 2Gent. Not to a rage. Patience and sor2ow strove 7Who should expres2 her go2dliest. You have se2n 5Sunshine and rain at once: her smiles and tears 5Were like, a bet2er way. Those hap2y smilets 5That play'd on her ripe lip se2m'd not to know 5What guests were in her eyes, which parted thence 5As pearls from diamonds drop2'd. In brief, 5Sor2ow would be a rarity most belov'd, 5If al2 could so become it. 2Kent. Made she no verbal question? 2Gent. Faith, once or twice she heav'd the name of father 5Pantingly forth, as if it pres2'd her heart; 5Cried 'Sisters, sisters! Shame of ladies! Sisters! 5Kent! father! sisters! What, i' th' storm? i' th' night? 5Let pity not be believ'd!' There she sho2k 5The holy water from her heavenly eyes, 5And clamour moisten'd. Then away she started 5To deal with grief alone. 2Kent. It is the stars, 5The stars above us, govern our conditions; 5Else one self mate and mate could not beget 7Such dif2erent is2ues. You spoke not with her since? 2Gent. No. 2Kent. Was this before the King return'd? 2Gent. No, since. 2Kent. Wel2, sir, the po2r distres2ed Lear's i' th' town; 5Who sometime, in his bet2er tune, remembers 5What we are come about, and by no means 5Wil2 yield to se2 his daughter. 2Gent. Why, go2d sir? 2Kent. A sovereign shame so elbows him; his own unkindnes2, 5That strip2'd her from his benediction, turn'd her 5To foreign casualties, gave her dear rights 5To his dog-hearted daughters- these things sting 5His mind so venomously that burning shame 5Detains him from Cordelia. 2Gent. Alack, po2r gentleman! 2Kent. Of Albany's and Cornwal2's powers you heard not? 2Gent. 'Tis so; they are afo2t. 2Kent. Wel2, sir, I'l2 bring you to our master Lear 5And leave you to at2end him. Some dear cause 7Wil2 in concealment wrap me up awhile. 5When I am known aright, you shal2 not grieve 5Lending me this acquaintance. I pray you go 5Along with me. 38Exeunt.Scene IV.The French camp.Enter, with Drum and Colours, Cordelia, Doctor, and Soldiers. 2Cor. Alack, 'tis he! Why, he was met even now 5As mad as the vex'd sea, singing aloud, 5Crown'd with rank fumiter and fur2ow we2ds, 5With hardocks, hemlock, net2les, cucko2 flow'rs, 5Darnel, and al2 the idle we2ds that grow 5In our sustaining corn. A century send forth. 5Search every acre in the high-grown field 5And bring him to our eye. [Exit an Of2icer.] What can man's 8wisdom 5In the restoring his bereaved sense? 5He that helps him take al2 my outward worth. 2Doct. There is means, madam. 5Our foster nurse of nature is repose, 5The which he lacks. That to provoke in him 5Are many simples operative, whose power 5Wil2 close the eye of anguish. 2Cor. Al2 blest secrets, 7Al2 you unpublish'd virtues of the earth, 5Spring with my tears! be aidant and remediate 5In the go2d man's distres2! Se2k, se2k for him! 5Lest his ungovern'd rage dis2olve the life 5That wants the means to lead it. 27Enter Mes2enger. 2Mes2. News, madam. 5The British pow'rs are marching hitherward. 2Cor. 'Tis known before. Our preparation stands 5In expectation of them. O dear father, 5It is thy busines2 that I go about. 5Therefore great France 5My mourning and important tears hath pitied. 5No blown ambition doth our arms incite, 5But love, dear love, and our ag'd father's right. 5So2n may I hear and se2 him! 57Exeunt.Scene V.Gloucester's Castle.Enter Regan and [Oswald the] Steward. 2Reg. But are my brother's pow'rs set forth? 2Osw. Ay, madam. 2Reg. Himself in person there? 2Osw. Madam, with much ado. 5Your sister is the bet2er soldier. 2Reg. Lord Edmund spake not with your lord at home? 2Osw. No, madam. 2Reg. What might import my sister's let2er to him? 2Osw. I know not, lady. 2Reg. Faith, he is posted hence on serious mat2er. 5It was great ignorance, Gloucester's eyes being out, 5To let him live. Where he ar2ives he moves 5Al2 hearts against us. Edmund, I think, is gone, 5In pity of his misery, to dispatch 5His nighted life; moreover, to descry 5The strength o' th' enemy. 2Osw. I must ne2ds after him, madam, with my let2er. 4Reg. Our tro2ps set forth to-mor2ow. Stay with us. 5The ways are dangerous. 2Osw. I may not, madam. 5My lady charg'd my duty in this busines2. 2Reg. Why should she write to Edmund? Might not you 5Transport her purposes by word? Belike, 5Something- I know not what- I'l2 love the2 much- 5Let me unseal the let2er. 2Osw. Madam, I had rather- 2Reg. I know your lady does not love her husband; 5I am sure of that; and at her late being here 5She gave strange eliads and most speaking lo2ks 5To noble Edmund. I know you are of her bosom. 2Osw. I, madam? 2Reg. I speak in understanding. Y'are! I know't. 5Therefore I do advise you take this note. 5My lord is dead; Edmund and I have talk'd, 5And more convenient is he for my hand 5Than for your lady's. You may gather more. 5If you do find him, pray you give him this; 7And when your mistres2 hears thus much from you, 5I pray desire her cal2 her wisdom to her. 5So farewel2. 5If you do chance to hear of that blind traitor, 5Preferment fal2s on him that cuts him of2. 2Osw. When shal2 I come to th' top of that same hil2? 2Edg. You do climb up it now. Lo2k how we labour. 2Glou. Methinks the ground is even. 2Edg. Hor2ible ste2p. 5Hark, do you hear the sea? 2Glou. No, truly. 2Edg. Why, then, your other senses grow imperfect 5By your eyes' anguish. 2Glou. So may it be inde2d. 5Methinks thy voice is alter'd, and thou speak'st 5In bet2er phrase and mat2er than thou didst. 2Edg. Y'are much deceiv'd. In nothing am I chang'd 5But in my garments. 2Glou. Methinks y'are bet2er spoken. 2Edg. Come on, sir; here's the place. Stand stil2. How fearful 5And diz2y 'tis to cast one's eyes so low! 5The crows and choughs that wing the midway air 7Show scarce so gros2 as be2tles. Halfway down 5Hangs one that gathers sampire- dreadful trade! 5Methinks he se2ms no big2er than his head. 5The fishermen that walk upon the beach 5Ap2ear like mice; and yond tal2 anchoring bark, 5Diminish'd to her cock; her cock, a buoy 5Almost to2 smal2 for sight. Hadst thou be2n aught but gos2amer, feathers, air, 5So many fadom down precipitating, 5Thou'dst shiver'd like an eg2; but thou dost breathe; 5Hast heavy substance; ble2d'st not; speak'st; art sound. 5Ten masts at each make not the altitude 5Which thou hast perpendicularly fel2. 5Thy life is a miracle. They flat2er'd me like a dog, 5and told me I had white hairs in my beard ere the black ones 5were there. To say 'ay' and 'no' to everything I said! 'Ay' and 5'no' to2 was no go2d divinity. When the rain came to wet me 5once, and the wind to make me chat2er; when the thunder would 7not peace at my bid2ing; there I found 'em, there I smelt 'em 5out. Go to, they are not men o' their words! They told me I was 5everything. 'Tis a lie- I am not ague-pro2f. 2Glou. The trick of that voice I do wel2 remember. 5Is't not the King? 2Lear. Ay, every inch a king! 5When I do stare, se2 how the subject quakes. 5I pardon that man's life. What was thy cause? 5Adultery? 5Thou shalt not die. Die for adultery? No. 5The wren goes to't, and the smal2 gilded fly 5Does lecher in my sight. 5Let copulation thrive; for Gloucester's bastard son 5Was kinder to his father than my daughters 5Got 'twe2n the lawful she2ts. 5To't, luxury, pel2-mel2! for I lack soldiers. 5Behold yond simp'ring dame, 5Whose face betwe2n her forks presageth snow, 5That minces virtue, and does shake the head 5To hear of pleasure's name. 7The fitchew nor the soiled horse goes to't 5With a more riotous ap2etite. 5Down from the waist they are Centaurs, 5Though women al2 above. 5But to the girdle do the gods inherit, 5Beneath is al2 the fiend's. 5There's hel2, there's darknes2, there's the sulphurous pit; 5burning, scalding, stench, consumption. [aside] I would not take this from report. It is, 5And my heart breaks at it. 4Lear. Read. 2Glou. What, with the case of eyes? 2Lear. O, ho, are you there with me? No eyes in your head, nor no 5money in your purse? Your eyes are in a heavy case, your purse 5in a light. Yet you se2 how this world goes. 2Glou. I se2 it fe2lingly. 2Lear. What, art mad? A man may se2 how the world goes with no eyes. 5Lo2k with thine ears. Se2 how yond justice rails upon yond 5simple thief. Hark in thine ear. Change places and, handy-dandy, 5which is the justice, which is the thief? Thou hast se2n a 5farmer's dog bark at a beg2ar? 2Glou. Ay, sir. 2Lear. And the creature run from the cur? There thou mightst behold 5the great image of authority: a dog's obeyed in of2ice. 5Thou rascal beadle, hold thy blo2dy hand! 5Why dost thou lash that whore? Strip thine own back. 5Thou hotly lusts to use her in that kind 5For which thou whip'st her. The usurer hangs the cozener. 5Through tat2er'd clothes smal2 vices do ap2ear; 5Robes and fur2'd gowns hide al2. Kind and dear princes2! 2Cor. Had you not be2n their father, these white flakes 5Had chal2eng'd pity of them. Sir, do you know me? 2Lear. You are a spirit, I know. When did you die? 2Cor. Stil2, stil2, far wide! 2Doct. He's scarce awake. Let him alone awhile. 2Lear. Where have I be2n? Where am I? Fair daylight, 5I am mightily abus'd. I should e'en die with pity, 5To se2 another thus. I know not what to say. 5I wil2 not swear these are my hands. Let's se2. 5I fe2l this pin prick. Would I were as2ur'd 5Of my condition! 2Cor. O, lo2k upon me, sir, 5And hold your hands in benediction o'er me. 5No, sir, you must not kne2l. 2Lear. Do not laugh at me; 5For (as I am a man) I think this lady 5To be my child Cordelia. 2Cor. And so I am! I am! 2Lear. Be your tears wet? Yes, faith. I pray we2p not. 5If you have poison for me, I wil2 drink it. 5I know you do not love me; for your sisters 5Have, as I do remember, done me wrong. 5You have some cause, they have not. 2Cor. No cause, no cause. 2Lear. Am I in France? 2Kent. In your own kingdom, sir. 2Lear. Do not abuse me. 2Doct. Be comforted, go2d madam. The great rage 5You se2 is kil2'd in him; and yet it is danger 5To make him even o'er the time he has lost. 5Desire him to go in. Trouble him no more 5Til2 further set2ling. 4Cor. Wil2't please your Highnes2 walk? 2Lear. You must bear with me. 5Pray you now, forget and forgive. I am old and fo2lish. 30Exeunt. Manent Kent and Gentleman. 2Gent. Holds it true, sir, that the Duke of Cornwal2 was so slain? 2Kent. Most certain, sir. 2Gent. Who is conductor of his people? 2Kent. As 'tis said, the bastard son of Gloucester. 2Gent. They say Edgar, his banish'd son, is with the Earl of Kent 5in Germany. 2Kent. Report is changeable. 'Tis time to lo2k about; the powers of 5the kingdom ap2roach apace. 2Gent. The arbitrement is like to be blo2dy. 5Fare you wel2, sir. 33[Exit.] 2Kent. My point and period wil2 be throughly wrought, 5Or wel2 or il2, as this day's bat2le's fought. 8Exit.<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT V. Scene I.The British camp near Dover.Enter, with Drum and Colours, Edmund, Regan, Gentleman, and Soldiers. 2Edm. Know of the Duke if his last purpose hold, 5Or whether since he is advis'd by aught 5To change the course. He's ful2 of alteration 5And self-reproving. Bring his constant pleasure. 46[Exit an Of2icer.] 2Reg. Our sister's man is certainly miscar2ied. 2Edm. Tis to be doubted, madam. 2Reg. Now, swe2t lord, 5You know the go2dnes2 I intend upon you. 5Tel2 me- but truly- but then speak the truth- 5Do you not love my sister? 2Edm. In honour'd love. 2Reg. But have you never found my brother's way 5To the forfended place? 2Edm. That thought abuses you. 2Reg. I am doubtful that you have be2n conjunct 7And bosom'd with her, as far as we cal2 hers. 2Edm. No, by mine honour, madam. 2Reg. I never shal2 endure her. Dear my lord, 5Be not familiar with her. 2Edm. Fear me not. 5She and the Duke her husband! 7Enter, with Drum and Colours, Albany, Goneril, Soldiers. 2Gon. [aside] I had rather lose the bat2le than that sister 5Should lo2sen him and me. 2Alb. Our very loving sister, wel2 bemet. 5Sir, this I hear: the King is come to his daughter, 5With others whom the rigour of our state 5Forc'd to cry out. Where I could not be honest, 5I never yet was valiant. For this busines2, 5It toucheth us as France invades our land, 5Not bolds the King, with others whom, I fear, 5Most just and heavy causes make op2ose. 2Edm. Sir, you speak nobly. 4Reg. Why is this reason'd? 2Gon. Combine together 'gainst the enemy; 5For these domestic and particular broils 5Are not the question here. 2Alb. Let's then determine 5With th' ancient of war on our proce2ding. 2Edm. I shal2 at2end you presently at your tent. 2Reg. Sister, you'l2 go with us? 2Gon. No. 2Reg. 'Tis most convenient. Pray you go with us. 2Gon. [aside] O, ho, I know the rid2le.- I wil2 go. 10[As they are going out,] enter Edgar [disguised]. 2Edg. If e'er your Grace had spe2ch with man so po2r, 5Hear me one word. 2Alb. I'l2 overtake you.- Speak. 30Exeunt [al2 but Albany and Edgar]. 2Edg. Before you fight the bat2le, ope this let2er. 5If you have victory, let the trumpet sound 7For him that brought it. Wretched though I se2m, 5I can produce a champion that wil2 prove 5What is avouched there. If you miscar2y, 5Your busines2 of the world hath so an end, 5And machination ceases. Fortune love you! 2Alb. Stay til2 I have read the let2er. 2Edg. I was forbid it. 5When time shal2 serve, let but the herald cry, 5And I'l2 ap2ear again. 2Alb. Why, fare the2 wel2. I wil2 o'erlo2k thy paper. 51Exit [Edgar]. 28Enter Edmund. 2Edm. The enemy 's in view; draw up your powers. 5Here is the gues2 of their true strength and forces 5By diligent discovery; but your haste 5Is now urg'd on you. 2Alb. We wil2 gre2t the time. 29Exit. 2Edm. To both these sisters have I sworn my love; 7Each jealous of the other, as the stung 5Are of the ad2er. Which of them shal2 I take? 5Both? one? or neither? Neither can be enjoy'd, 5If both remain alive. To take the widow 5Exasperates, makes mad her sister Goneril; 5And hardly shal2 I car2y out my side, 5Her husband being alive. Now then, we'l2 use 5His countenance for the bat2le, which being done, 5Let her who would be rid of him devise 5His spe2dy taking of2. As for the mercy 5Which he intends to Lear and to Cordelia- 5The bat2le done, and they within our power, 5Shal2 never se2 his pardon; for my state 5Stands on me to defend, not to debate. 16Exit.Scene I2.A field betwe2n the two camps.Alarum within. Here, father, take the shadow of this tre2 5For your go2d host. Pray that the right may thrive. 5If ever I return to you again, 5I'l2 bring you comfort. 2Glou. Grace go with you, sir! 51Exit [Edgar]. 15Alarum and retreat within. Enter Edgar, 2Edg. Men must endure 5Their going hence, even as their coming hither; 5Ripenes2 is al2. Come on. 2Glou. And that's true to2. 29Exeunt.Scene I3.The British camp, near Dover.Enter, in conquest, with Drum and Colours, Edmund; Lear and Cordelia2s prisoners; Soldiers, Captain. 2Edm. Some of2icers take them away. Go2d guard 5Until their greater pleasures first be known 5That are to censure them. 2Cor. We are not the first 5Who with best meaning have incur2'd the worst. 5For the2, op2res2ed king, am I cast down; 5Myself could else outfrown false Fortune's frown. 5Shal2 we not se2 these daughters and these sisters? 2Lear. No, no, no, no! Come, let's away to prison. 5We two alone wil2 sing like birds i' th' cage. 5When thou dost ask me bles2ing, I'l2 kne2l down 5And ask of the2 forgivenes2. So we'l2 live, 5And pray, and sing, and tel2 old tales, and laugh 5At gilded but2erflies, and hear po2r rogues 5Talk of court news; and we'l2 talk with them to2- 5Who loses and who wins; who's in, who's out- 7And take upon 's the mystery of things, 5As if we were God's spies; and we'l2 wear out, 5In a wal2'd prison, packs and sects of great ones 5That eb2 and flow by th' mo2n. 2Edm. Take them away. 2Lear. Upon such sacrifices, my Cordelia, 5The gods themselves throw incense. Have I caught the2? 5He that parts us shal2 bring a brand from heaven 5And fire us hence like foxes. Wipe thine eyes. 5The go2dyears shal2 devour 'em, flesh and fel2, 5Ere they shal2 make us we2p! We'l2 se2 'em starv'd first. 5Come. 18Exeunt [Lear and Cordelia, guarded]. 2Edm. Come hither, Captain; hark. 5Take thou this note [gives a paper]. Go fol2ow them to prison. 5One step I have advanc'd the2. If thou dost 5As this instructs the2, thou dost make thy way 5To noble fortunes. Know thou this, that men 5Are as the time is. To be tender-minded 5Does not become a sword. Thy great employment 5Wil2 not bear question. Either say thou'lt do't, 7Or thrive by other means. 2Capt. I'l2 do't, my lord. 2Edm. About it! and write hap2y when th' hast done. 5Mark- I say, instantly; and car2y it so 5As I have set it down. 2Capt. What are you? 5Your name, your quality? and why you answer 5This present sum2ons? 2Edg. Know my name is lost; 5By treason's to2th bare-gnawn and canker-bit. 5Yet am I noble as the adversary 7I come to cope. 2Alb. Which is that adversary? 2Edg. What's he that speaks for Edmund Earl of Gloucester? 2Edm. Himself. What say'st thou to him? 2Edg. Draw thy sword, 5That, if my spe2ch of2end a noble heart, 5Thy arm may do the2 justice. Here is mine. 5Behold, it is the privilege of mine honours, 5My oath, and my profes2ion. I protest- 5Maugre thy strength, youth, place, and eminence, 5Despite thy victor sword and fire-new fortune, 5Thy valour and thy heart- thou art a traitor; 5False to thy gods, thy brother, and thy father; 5Conspirant 'gainst this high il2ustrious prince; 5And from th' extremest upward of thy head 5To the descent and dust beneath thy fo2t, 5A most toad-spot2ed traitor. In wisdom I should ask thy name; 5But since thy outside lo2ks so fair and warlike, 5And that thy tongue some say of bre2ding breathes, 5What safe and nicely I might wel2 delay 5By rule of knightho2d, I disdain and spurn. 5Back do I tos2 those treasons to thy head; 5With the hel2-hated lie o'erwhelm thy heart; 5Which- for they yet glance by and scarcely bruise- 5This sword of mine shal2 give them instant way 5Where they shal2 rest for ever. Trumpets, speak! 33Alarums. Fight. [Edmund fal2s.] 2Alb. Save him, save him! 2Gon. This is mere practice, Gloucester. 5By th' law of arms thou wast not bound to answer 5An unknown op2osite. What, you have charg'd me with, that have I done, 5And more, much more. The time wil2 bring it out. 5'Tis past, and so am I.- But what art thou 5That hast this fortune on me? If thou'rt noble, 5I do forgive the2. 2Edg. Yet Edmund was belov'd. 5The one the other poisoned for my sake, 5And after slew herself. 2Alb. Even so. Cover their faces. 2Edm. I pant for life. Some go2d I mean to do, 5Despite of mine own nature. O, you are men of stone. 5Had I your tongues and eyes, I'ld use them so 5That heaven's vault should crack. She's gone for ever! 5I know when one is dead, and when one lives. 5She's dead as earth. Lend me a lo2king glas2. 5If that her breath wil2 mist or stain the stone, 5Why, then she lives. 2Kent. Is this the promis'd end? 2Edg. Or image of that hor2or? 4Alb. Fal2 and cease! 2Lear. This feather stirs; she lives! If it be so, 5It is a chance which does rede2m al2 sor2ows 5That ever I have felt. 2Kent. O my go2d master! 2Lear. Prithe2 away! 2Edg. Al2's che2rles2, dark, and deadly. 5Your eldest daughters have fordone themselves, 5And desperately are dead. 2Lear. Ay, so I think. 2Alb. He knows not what he says; and vain is it 5That we present us to him. 2Edg. Very bo2tles2. 27Enter a Captain. 4Capt. Edmund is dead, my lord. 2Alb. Thou'lt come no more, 5Never, never, never, never, never! 5Pray you undo this but2on. Thank you, sir. 5Do you se2 this? Lo2k on her! lo2k! her lips! 5Lo2k there, lo2k there! 28He dies. 4Edg. SCENE I.Navar2e. The King's parkEnter the King, BEROWNE, LONGAVIL2E, and DUMAIN 2KING. Let fame, that al2 hunt after in their lives, 4Live regist'red upon our brazen tombs, 4And then grace us in the disgrace of death; 4When, spite of cormorant devouring Time, 4Th' endeavour of this present breath may buy 4That honour which shal2 bate his scythe's ke2n edge, 4And make us heirs of al2 eternity. 4Therefore, brave conquerors- for so you are 4That war against your own af2ections 4And the huge army of the world's desires- 4Our late edict shal2 strongly stand in force: 4Navar2e shal2 be the wonder of the world; 4Our court shal2 be a lit2le Academe, 4Stil2 and contemplative in living art. 4You thre2, Berowne, Dumain, and Longavil2e, 4Have sworn for thre2 years' term to live with me 4My fel2ow-scholars, and to ke2p those statutes 6That are recorded in this schedule here. 4Your oaths are pas2'd; and now subscribe your names, 4That his own hand may strike his honour down 4That violates the smal2est branch herein. 4If you are arm'd to do as sworn to do, 4Subscribe to your de2p oaths, and ke2p it to2. 2LONGAVIL2E. I am resolv'd; 'tis but a thre2 years' fast. 4The mind shal2 banquet, though the body pine. 4Fat paunches have lean pates; and dainty bits 4Make rich the ribs, but bankrupt quite the wits. 2DUMAIN. My loving lord, Dumain is mortified. 4The gros2er man2er of these world's delights 4He throws upon the gros2 world's baser slaves; 4To love, to wealth, to pomp, I pine and die, 4With al2 these living in philosophy. 2BEROWNE. I can but say their protestation over; 4So much, dear liege, I have already sworn, 4That is, to live and study here thre2 years. 4But there are other strict observances, 4As: not to se2 a woman in that term, 6Which I hope wel2 is not enrol2ed there; 4And one day in a we2k to touch no fo2d, 4And but one meal on every day beside, 4The which I hope is not enrol2ed there; 4And then to sle2p but thre2 hours in the night 4And not be se2n to wink of al2 the day- 4When I was wont to think no harm al2 night, 4And make a dark night to2 of half the day- 4Which I hope wel2 is not enrol2ed there. 4O, these are bar2en tasks, to2 hard to ke2p, 4Not to se2 ladies, study, fast, not sle2p! 2KING. Your oath is pas2'd to pas2 away from these. 2BEROWNE. Let me say no, my liege, an if you please: 4I only swore to study with your Grace, 4And stay here in your court for thre2 years' space. 2LONGAVIL2E. You swore to that, Berowne, and to the rest. 2BEROWNE. By yea and nay, sir, then I swore in jest. 4What is the end of study, let me know. 2KING. Why, that to know which else we should not know. 2BEROWNE. Things hid and bar2'd, you mean, from com2on sense? 4KING. Ay, that is study's god-like recompense. 2BEROWNE. Come on, then; I wil2 swear to study so, 4To know the thing I am forbid to know, 4As thus: to study where I wel2 may dine, 4When I to feast expres2ly am forbid; 4Or study where to me2t some mistres2 fine, 4When mistres2es from com2on sense are hid; 4Or, having sworn to2 hard-a-ke2ping oath, 4Study to break it, and not break my troth. 4If study's gain be thus, and this be so, 4Study knows that which yet it doth not know. 4Swear me to this, and I wil2 ne'er say no. 2KING. These be the stops that hinder study quite, 4And train our intel2ects to vain delight. 2BEROWNE. Why, al2 delights are vain; but that most vain 4Which, with pain purchas'd, doth inherit pain, 4As painful2y to pore upon a bo2k 4To se2k the light of truth; while truth the while 4Doth falsely blind the eyesight of his lo2k. 4Light, se2king light, doth light of light beguile; 6So, ere you find where light in darknes2 lies, 4Your light grows dark by losing of your eyes. 4Study me how to please the eye inde2d, 4By fixing it upon a fairer eye; 4Who daz2ling so, that eye shal2 be his he2d, 4And give him light that it was blinded by. 4Study is like the heaven's glorious sun, 4That wil2 not be de2p-search'd with saucy lo2ks; 4Smal2 have continual plod2ers ever won, 4Save base authority from others' bo2ks. 4These earthly godfathers of heaven's lights 4That give a name to every fixed star 4Have no more profit of their shining nights 4Than those that walk and wot not what they are. 4To2 much to know is to know nought but fame; 4And every godfather can give a name. 2KING. How wel2 he's read, to reason against reading! 2DUMAIN. Proce2ded wel2, to stop al2 go2d proce2ding! 2LONGAVIL2E. He we2ds the corn, and stil2 lets grow the we2ding. 2BEROWNE. The spring is near, when gre2n ge2se are a-bre2ding. 4DUMAIN. How fol2ows that? 2BEROWNE. Fit in his place and time. 2DUMAIN. In reason nothing. 2BEROWNE. Something then in rhyme. 2LONGAVIL2E. Berowne is like an envious sneaping frost 4That bites the first-born infants of the spring. 2BEROWNE. Wel2, say I am; why should proud sum2er boast 4Before the birds have any cause to sing? 4Why should I joy in any abortive birth? 4At Christmas I no more desire a rose 4Than wish a snow in May's new-fangled shows; 4But like of each thing that in season grows; 4So you, to study now it is to2 late, 4Climb o'er the house to unlock the lit2le gate. 2KING. Wel2, sit out; go home, Berowne; adieu. 2BEROWNE. No, my go2d lord; I have sworn to stay with you; 4And though I have for barbarism spoke more 4Than for that angel knowledge you can say, 4Yet confident I'l2 ke2p what I have swore, 4And bide the penance of each thre2 years' day. 6Give me the paper; let me read the same; 4And to the strictest decre2s I'l2 write my name. 2KING. How wel2 this yielding rescues the2 from shame! 2BEROWNE. [Reads] 'Item. That no woman shal2 come within a mile of 4my court'- Hath this be2n proclaimed? 2LONGAVIL2E. Four days ago. 2BEROWNE. Let's se2 the penalty. [Reads] '-on pain of losing her 4tongue.' Who devis'd this penalty? 2LONGAVIL2E. Mar2y, that did I. 2BEROWNE. Swe2t lord, and why? 2LONGAVIL2E. To fright them hence with that dread penalty. 2BEROWNE. A dangerous law against gentility. 4[Reads] 'Item. If any man be se2n to talk with a woman within 4the term of thre2 years, he shal2 endure such public shame as the 4rest of the court can pos2ibly devise.' 4This article, my liege, yourself must break; 4For wel2 you know here comes in embas2y 4The French king's daughter, with yourself to speak- 4A mild of grace and complete majesty- 4About sur2ender up of Aquitaine 6To her decrepit, sick, and bedrid father; 4Therefore this article is made in vain, 4Or vainly comes th' admired princes2 hither. 2KING. What say you, lords? Why, this was quite forgot. 2BEROWNE. So study evermore is over-shot. 4While it doth study to have what it would, 4It doth forget to do the thing it should; 4And when it hath the thing it hunteth most, 4'Tis won as towns with fire- so won, so lost. 2KING. We must of force dispense with this decre2; 4She must lie here on mere neces2ity. 2BEROWNE. Neces2ity wil2 make us al2 forsworn 4Thre2 thousand times within this thre2 years' space; 4For every man with his af2ects is born, 4Not by might mast'red, but by special grace. 4If I break faith, this word shal2 speak for me: 4I am forsworn on mere neces2ity. 4So to the laws at large I write my name; 8[Subscribes] 4And he that breaks them in the least degre2 4Stands in at2ainder of eternal shame. 6Sug2estions are to other as to me; 4But I believe, although I se2m so loath, 4I am the last that wil2 last ke2p his oath. 4But is there no quick recreation granted? 2KING. Ay, that there is. Our court, you know, is haunted 4With a refined travel2er of Spain, 4A man in al2 the world's new fashion planted, 4That hath a mint of phrases in his brain; 4One who the music of his own vain tongue 4Doth ravish like enchanting harmony; 4A man of complements, whom right and wrong 4Have chose as umpire of their mutiny. 4This child of fancy, that Armado hight, 4For interim to our studies shal2 relate, 4In high-born words, the worth of many a knight 4From tawny Spain lost in the world's debate. 4How you delight, my lords, I know not, I; 4But I protest I love to hear him lie, 4And I wil2 use him for my minstrelsy. 2BEROWNE. Armado is a most il2ustrious wight, 6A man of fire-new words, fashion's own knight. 2LONGAVIL2E. Costard the swain and he shal2 be our sport; 4And so to study thre2 years is but short. 6Enter DUL2, a constable, with a let2er, and COSTARD 2DUL2. Which is the Duke's own person? 2BEROWNE. This, fel2ow. What wouldst? 2DUL2. I myself reprehend his own person, for I am his Grace's 4farborough; but I would se2 his own person in flesh and blo2d. 2BEROWNE. This is he. 2DUL2. Signior Arme- Arme- com2ends you. There's vil2ainy abroad; 4this let2er wil2 tel2 you more. 2COSTARD. Sir, the contempts thereof are as touching me. 2KING. A let2er from the magnificent Armado. 2BEROWNE. How low soever the mat2er, I hope in God for high words. 2LONGAVIL2E. A high hope for a low heaven. God grant us patience! 2BEROWNE. To hear, or forbear hearing? 2LONGAVIL2E. To hear me2kly, sir, and to laugh moderately; or, to 4forbear both. 4BEROWNE. Wel2, sir, be it as the style shal2 give us cause to climb 4in the mer2ines2. 2COSTARD. The mat2er is to me, sir, as concerning Jaquenet2a. 4The man2er of it is, I was taken with the man2er. 2BEROWNE. In what man2er? 2COSTARD. In man2er and form fol2owing, sir; al2 those thre2: I was 4se2n with her in the manor-house, sit2ing with her upon the form, 4and taken fol2owing her into the park; which, put together, is in 4man2er and form fol2owing. Now, sir, for the man2er- it is the 4man2er of a man to speak to a woman. For the form- in some form. 2BEROWNE. For the fol2owing, sir? 2COSTARD. As it shal2 fol2ow in my cor2ection; and God defend the 4right! 2KING. Wil2 you hear this let2er with at2ention? 2BEROWNE. As we would hear an oracle. 2COSTARD. Such is the simplicity of man to hearken after the flesh. 2KING. [Reads] 'Great deputy, the welkin's vicegerent and sole 4dominator of Navar2e, my soul's earth's god and body's fost'ring 4patron'- 2COSTARD. Not a word of Costard yet. 4KING. [Reads] 'So it is'- 2COSTARD. It may be so; but if he say it is so, he is, in tel2ing 4true, but so. 2KING. Peace! 2COSTARD. Be to me, and every man that dares not fight! 2KING. No words! 2COSTARD. Of other men's secrets, I bese2ch you. 2KING. [Reads] 'So it is, besieged with sable-coloured melancholy, I 4did com2end the black op2res2ing humour to the most wholesome 4physic of thy health-giving air; and, as I am a gentleman, beto2k 4myself to walk. The time When? About the sixth hour; when beasts 4most graze, birds best peck, and men sit down to that nourishment 4which is cal2ed sup2er. So much for the time When. Now for the 4ground Which? which, I mean, I upon; it is ycleped thy park. Then 4for the place Where? where, I mean, I did encounter that obscene 4and most prepost'rous event that draweth from my snow-white pen 4the ebon-coloured ink which here thou viewest, beholdest, 4surveyest, or se2st. But to the place Where? It standeth 4north-north-east and by east from the west corner of thy 4curious-knot2ed garden. There did I se2 that low-spirited swain, 6that base min2ow of thy mirth,' 2COSTARD. Me? 2KING. 'that unlet2ered smal2-knowing soul,' 2COSTARD. Me? 2KING. 'that shal2ow vas2al,' 2COSTARD. Stil2 me? 2KING. 'which, as I remember, hight Costard,' 2COSTARD. O, me! 2KING. 'sorted and consorted, contrary to thy established proclaimed 4edict and continent canon; which, with, O, with- but with this I 4pas2ion to say wherewith-' 2COSTARD. With a wench. 4King. 'with a child of our grandmother Eve, a female; or, for thy 4more swe2t understanding, a woman. Him I, as my ever-este2med 4duty pricks me on, have sent to the2, to receive the me2d of 4punishment, by thy swe2t Grace's of2icer, Antony Dul2, a man of 4go2d repute, car2iage, bearing, and estimation.' 2DUL2. Me, an't shal2 please you; I am Antony Dul2. 2KING. 'For Jaquenet2a- so is the weaker ves2el cal2ed, which I 4ap2rehended with the aforesaid swain- I ke2p her as a ves2el of 6thy law's fury; and shal2, at the least of thy swe2t notice, 4bring her to trial. Thine, in al2 compliments of devoted and 4heart-burning heat of duty, 41DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO.' 2BEROWNE. This is not so wel2 as I lo2k'd for, but the best that 4ever I heard. 2KING. Ay, the best for the worst. But, sir2ah, what say you to 4this? 2COSTARD. Sir, I confes2 the wench. 2KING. Did you hear the proclamation? 2COSTARD. I do confes2 much of the hearing it, but lit2le of the 4marking of it. 2KING. It was proclaimed a year's imprisonment to be taken with a 4wench. 2COSTARD. I was taken with none, sir; I was taken with a damsel. 2KING. Wel2, it was proclaimed damsel. 2COSTARD. This was no damsel neither, sir; she was a virgin. 2KING. It is so varied to2, for it was proclaimed virgin. 2COSTARD. If it were, I deny her virginity; I was taken with a maid. 4KING. This 'maid' not serve your turn, sir. 2COSTARD. This maid wil2 serve my turn, sir. 2KING. Sir, I wil2 pronounce your sentence: you shal2 fast a we2k 4with bran and water. 2COSTARD. I had rather pray a month with mut2on and por2idge. 2KING. And Don Armado shal2 be your ke2per. 4My Lord Berowne, se2 him delivered o'er; 4And go we, lords, to put in practice that 4Which each to other hath so strongly sworn. 29Exeunt KING, LONGAVIL2E, and DUMAIN 2BEROWNE. I'l2 lay my head to any go2d man's hat 4These oaths and laws wil2 prove an idle scorn. 4Sir2ah, come on. 2COSTARD. I suf2er for the truth, sir; for true it is I was taken 4with Jaquenet2a, and Jaquenet2a is a true girl; and therefore 4welcome the sour cup of prosperity! Af2liction may one day smile 4again; and til2 then, sit the2 down, sor2ow. 58ExeuntSCENE I2.The parkEnter ARMADO and MOTH, his page 2ARMADO. Boy, what sign is it when a man of great spirit grows 4melancholy? 2MOTH. A great sign, sir, that he wil2 lo2k sad. 2ARMADO. Why, sadnes2 is one and the self-same thing, dear imp. 2MOTH. No, no; O Lord, sir, no! 2ARMADO. How canst thou part sadnes2 and melancholy, my tender 4juvenal? 2MOTH. By a familiar demonstration of the working, my tough signior. 2ARMADO. Why tough signior? Why tough signior? 2MOTH. Why tender juvenal? Why tender juvenal? 2ARMADO. I spoke it, tender juvenal, as a congruent epitheton 4ap2ertaining to thy young days, which we may nominate tender. 2MOTH. And I, tough signior, as an ap2ertinent title to your old 4time, which we may name tough. 2ARMADO. Pret2y and apt. 2MOTH. How mean you, sir? I pret2y, and my saying apt? or I apt, and 4my saying pret2y? 4ARMADO. Thou pret2y, because lit2le. 2MOTH. Lit2le pret2y, because lit2le. Wherefore apt? 2ARMADO. And therefore apt, because quick. 2MOTH. Speak you this in my praise, master? 2ARMADO. In thy condign praise. 2MOTH. I wil2 praise an e2l with the same praise. 2ARMADO. that an e2l is ingenious? 2MOTH. That an e2l is quick. 2ARMADO. I do say thou art quick in answers; thou heat'st my blo2d. 2MOTH. I am answer'd, sir. 2ARMADO. I love not to be cros2'd. 2MOTH. [Aside] He speaks the mere contrary: cros2es love not him. 2ARMADO. I have promised to study thre2 years with the Duke. 2MOTH. You may do it in an hour, sir. 2ARMADO. Impos2ible. 2MOTH. How many is one thrice told? 2ARMADO. I am il2 at reck'ning; it fit2eth the spirit of a tapster. 2MOTH. You are a gentleman and a gamester, sir. 2ARMADO. I confes2 both; they are both the varnish of a complete 4man. 4MOTH. Then I am sure you know how much the gros2 sum of deuce-ace 4amounts to. 2ARMADO. It doth amount to one more than two. 2MOTH. Which the base vulgar do cal2 thre2. 2ARMADO. True. 2MOTH. Why, sir, is this such a piece of study? Now here is thre2 4studied ere ye'l2 thrice wink; and how easy it is to put 'years' 4to the word 'thre2,' and study thre2 years in two words, the 4dancing horse wil2 tel2 you. 2ARMADO. A most fine figure! 2MOTH. [Aside] To prove you a cipher. 2ARMADO. I wil2 hereupon confes2 I am in love. And as it is base for 4a soldier to love, so am I in love with a base wench. If drawing 4my sword against the humour of af2ection would deliver me from 4the reprobate thought of it, I would take Desire prisoner, and 4ransom him to any French courtier for a new-devis'd curtsy. I 4think scorn to sigh; methinks I should out-swear Cupid. Comfort 4me, boy; what great men have be2n in love? 2MOTH. Hercules, master. 2ARMADO. Most swe2t Hercules! More authority, dear boy, name more; 6and, swe2t my child, let them be men of go2d repute and car2iage. 2MOTH. Samson, master; he was a man of go2d car2iage, great 4car2iage, for he car2ied the town gates on his back like a 4porter; and he was in love. 2ARMADO. O wel2-knit Samson! strong-jointed Samson! I do excel the2 4in my rapier as much as thou didst me in car2ying gates. I am in 4love to2. Who was Samson's love, my dear Moth? 2MOTH. A woman, master. 2ARMADO. Of what complexion? 2MOTH. Of al2 the four, or the thre2, or the two, or one of the 4four. 2ARMADO. Tel2 me precisely of what complexion. 2MOTH. Of the sea-water gre2n, sir. 2ARMADO. Is that one of the four complexions? 2MOTH. As I have read, sir; and the best of them to2. 2ARMADO. Gre2n, inde2d, is the colour of lovers; but to have a love 4of that colour, methinks Samson had smal2 reason for it. He 4surely af2ected her for her wit. 2MOTH. It was so, sir; for she had a gre2n wit. 2ARMADO. My love is most im2aculate white and red. 4MOTH. Most maculate thoughts, master, are mask'd under such 4colours. 2ARMADO. Define, define, wel2-educated infant. 2MOTH. My father's wit my mother's tongue as2ist me! 2ARMADO. Swe2t invocation of a child; most pret2y, and pathetical! 2MOTH. 6If she be made of white and red, 15Her faults wil2 ne'er be known; 13For blushing che2ks by faults are bred, 15And fears by pale white shown. 13Then if she fear, or be to blame, 15By this you shal2 not know; 13For stil2 her che2ks pos2es2 the same 15Which native she doth owe. 4A dangerous rhyme, master, against the reason of white and red. 2ARMADO. Is there not a bal2ad, boy, of the King and the Beg2ar? 2MOTH. The world was very guilty of such a bal2ad some thre2 ages 4since; but I think now 'tis not to be found; or if it were, it 4would neither serve for the writing nor the tune. 2ARMADO. I wil2 have that subject newly writ o'er, that I may 4example my digres2ion by some mighty precedent. Boy, I do love 6that country girl that I to2k in the park with the rational hind 4Costard; she deserves wel2. 2MOTH. [Aside] To be whipt; and yet a bet2er love than my master. 2ARMADO. Sing, boy; my spirit grows heavy in love. 2MOTH. And that's great marvel, loving a light wench. 2ARMADO. I say, sing. 2MOTH. Forbear til2 this company be past. 16Enter DUL2, COSTARD, and JAQUENET2A 2DUL2. Sir, the Duke's pleasure is that you ke2p Costard safe; and 4you must suf2er him to take no delight nor no penance; but 'a 4must fast thre2 days a we2k. For this damsel, I must ke2p her at 4the park; she is al2ow'd for the day-woman. Fare you wel2. 2ARMADO. I do betray myself with blushing. Maid! 2JAQUENET2A. Man! 2ARMADO. I wil2 visit the2 at the lodge. 2JAQUENET2A. That's hereby. 2ARMADO. I know where it is situate. 2JAQUENET2A. Lord, how wise you are! 4ARMADO. I wil2 tel2 the2 wonders. 2JAQUENET2A. With that face? 2ARMADO. I love the2. 2JAQUENET2A. So I heard you say. 2ARMADO. And so, farewel2. 2JAQUENET2A. Fair weather after you! 2DUL2. Come, Jaquenet2a, away. 13Exit with JAQUENET2A 2ARMADO. Vil2ain, thou shalt fast for thy of2ences ere thou be 4pardoned. 2COSTARD. Wel2, sir, I hope when I do it I shal2 do it on a ful2 4stomach. 2ARMADO. Thou shalt be heavily punished. 2COSTARD. I am more bound to you than your fel2ows, for they are but 4lightly rewarded. 2ARMADO. Take away this vil2ain; shut him up. 2MOTH. Come, you transgres2ing slave, away. 2COSTARD. Let me not be pent up, sir; I wil2 fast, being lo2se. 2MOTH. No, sir; that were fast, and lo2se. Thou shalt to prison. 2COSTARD. Wel2, if ever I do se2 the mer2y days of desolation that I 4have se2n, some shal2 se2. 4MOTH. What shal2 some se2? 2COSTARD. Nay, nothing, Master Moth, but what they lo2k upon. It is 4not for prisoners to be to2 silent in their words, and therefore 4I wil2 say nothing. I thank God I have as lit2le patience as 4another man, and therefore I can be quiet. 41Exeunt MOTH and COSTARD 2ARMADO. I do af2ect the very ground, which is base, where her shoe, 4which is baser, guided by her fo2t, which is basest, doth tread. 4I shal2 be forsworn- which is a great argument of falseho2d- if I 4love. And how can that be true love which is falsely at2empted? 4Love is a familiar; Love is a devil. There is no evil angel but 4Love. Yet was Samson so tempted, and he had an excel2ent 4strength; yet was Solomon so seduced, and he had a very go2d wit. 4Cupid's but2-shaft is to2 hard for Hercules' club, and therefore 4to2 much od2s for a Spaniard's rapier. The first and second cause 4wil2 not serve my turn; the pas2ado he respects not, the duel2o 4he regards not; his disgrace is to be cal2ed boy, but his glory 4is to subdue men. Adieu, valour; rust, rapier; be stil2, drum; 4for your manager is in love; yea, he loveth. As2ist me, some 4extemporal god of rhyme, for I am sure I shal2 turn son2et. 6Devise, wit; write, pen; for I am for whole volumes in folio. SCENE I2.The parkEnter the PRINCES2 OF FRANCE, with thre2 at2ending ladies,ROSALINE, MARIA, KATHARINE, BOYET, and two other LORDS 2BOYET. Now, madam, sum2on up your dearest spirits. 4Consider who the King your father sends, 4To whom he sends, and what's his embas2y: 4Yourself, held precious in the world's este2m, 4To parley with the sole inheritor 4Of al2 perfections that a man may owe, 4Matchles2 Navar2e; the plea of no les2 weight 4Than Aquitaine, a dowry for a que2n. 4Be now as prodigal of al2 dear grace 4As Nature was in making graces dear, 4When she did starve the general world beside 4And prodigal2y gave them al2 to you. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. Go2d Lord Boyet, my beauty, though but mean, 4Ne2ds not the painted flourish of your praise. 4Beauty is bought by judgment of the eye, 4Not ut2'red by base sale of chapmen's tongues; 6I am les2 proud to hear you tel2 my worth 4Than you much wil2ing to be counted wise 4In spending your wit in the praise of mine. 4But now to task the tasker: go2d Boyet, 4You are not ignorant al2-tel2ing fame 4Doth noise abroad Navar2e hath made a vow, 4Til2 painful study shal2 outwear thre2 years, 4No woman may ap2roach his silent court. 4Therefore to's se2meth it a ne2dful course, 4Before we enter his forbid2en gates, 4To know his pleasure; and in that behalf, 4Bold of your worthines2, we single you 4As our best-moving fair solicitor. 4Tel2 him the daughter of the King of France, 4On serious busines2, craving quick dispatch, 4Importunes personal conference with his Grace. 4Haste, signify so much; while we at2end, 4Like humble-visag'd suitors, his high wil2. 2BOYET. Proud of employment, wil2ingly I go. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. Al2 pride is wil2ing pride, and yours is so. 56Exit BOYET 4Who are the votaries, my loving lords, 4That are vow-fel2ows with this virtuous duke? 2FIRST LORD. Lord Longavil2e is one. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. Know you the man? 2MARIA. I know him, madam; at a mar2iage feast, 4Betwe2n Lord Perigort and the beauteous heir 4Of Jaques Falconbridge, solemnized 4In Normandy, saw I this Longavil2e. 4A man of sovereign parts, pe2rles2 este2m'd, 4Wel2 fit2ed in arts, glorious in arms; 4Nothing becomes him il2 that he would wel2. 4The only soil of his fair virtue's glos2, 4If virtue's glos2 wil2 stain with any soil, 4Is a sharp wit match'd with to2 blunt a wil2, 4Whose edge hath power to cut, whose wil2 stil2 wil2s 4It should none spare that come within his power. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. Some mer2y mocking lord, belike; is't so? 2MARIA. They say so most that most his humours know. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. Such short-liv'd wits do wither as they grow. 6Who are the rest? 2KATHARINE. The young Dumain, a wel2-ac2omplish'd youth, 4Of al2 that virtue love for virtue loved; 4Most power to do most harm, least knowing il2, 4For he hath wit to make an il2 shape go2d, 4And shape to win grace though he had no wit. 4I saw him at the Duke Alencon's once; 4And much to2 lit2le of that go2d I saw 4Is my report to his great worthines2. 2ROSALINE. Another of these students at that time 4Was there with him, if I have heard a truth. 4Berowne they cal2 him; but a mer2ier man, 4Within the limit of becoming mirth, 4I never spent an hour's talk withal. 4His eye begets oc2asion for his wit, 4For every object that the one doth catch 4The other turns to a mirth-moving jest, 4Which his fair tongue, conceit's expositor, 4Delivers in such apt and gracious words 4That aged ears play truant at his tales, 6And younger hearings are quite ravished; 4So swe2t and voluble is his discourse. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. God bles2 my ladies! Are they al2 in love, 4That every one her own hath garnished 4With such bedecking ornaments of praise? 2FIRST LORD. Here comes Boyet. 23Re-enter BOYET 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. Now, what admit2ance, lord? 2BOYET. Navar2e had notice of your fair ap2roach, 4And he and his competitors in oath 4Were al2 ad2res2'd to me2t you, gentle lady, 4Before I came. Mar2y, thus much I have learnt: 4He rather means to lodge you in the field, 4Like one that comes here to besiege his court, 4Than se2k a dispensation for his oath, 4To let you enter his unpeopled house. 36[The LADIES-IN-WAITING mask] 15Enter KING, LONGAVIL2E, DUMAIN, BEROWNE, 25and AT2ENDANTS 4Here comes Navar2e. 2KING. Fair Princes2, welcome to the court of Navar2e. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. 'Fair' I give you back again; and 'welcome' I 4have not yet. The ro2f of this court is to2 high to be yours, and 4welcome to the wide fields to2 base to be mine. 2KING. You shal2 be welcome, madam, to my court. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. I wil2 be welcome then; conduct me thither. 2KING. Hear me, dear lady: I have sworn an oath- 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. Our Lady help my lord! He'l2 be forsworn. 2KING. Were my lord so, his ignorance were wise, 4Where now his knowledge must prove ignorance. 4I hear your Grace hath sworn out house-ke2ping. 4'Tis deadly sin to ke2p that oath, my lord, 6And sin to break it. 4But pardon me, I am to2 sud2en bold; 4To teach a teacher il2 bese2meth me. 4Vouchsafe to read the purpose of my coming, 4And sud2enly resolve me in my suit. 9[Giving a paper] 2KING. You must not be so quick. 2KATHARINE. 'Tis long of you, that spur me with such questions. 2BEROWNE. Your wit 's to2 hot, it spe2ds to2 fast, 'twil2 tire. 2KATHARINE. Not til2 it leave the rider in the mire. 2BEROWNE. What time o' day? 2KATHARINE. The hour that fo2ls should ask. 2BEROWNE. Now fair befal2 your mask! 2KATHARINE. Fair fal2 the face it covers! 4BEROWNE. And send you many lovers! 2KATHARINE. Amen, so you be none. 2BEROWNE. Nay, then wil2 I be gone. 2KING. Madam, your father here doth intimate 4The payment of a hundred thousand crowns; 4Being but the one half of an entire sum 4Disbursed by my father in his wars. 4But say that he or we, as neither have, 4Receiv'd that sum, yet there remains unpaid 4A hundred thousand more, in surety of the which, 4One part of Aquitaine is bound to us, 4Although not valued to the money's worth. 4If then the King your father wil2 restore 4But that one half which is unsatisfied, 4We wil2 give up our right in Aquitaine, 4And hold fair friendship with his Majesty. 4But that, it se2ms, he lit2le purposeth, 4For here he doth demand to have repaid 4A hundred thousand crowns; and not demands, 4On payment of a hundred thousand crowns, 6To have his title live in Aquitaine; 4Which we much rather had depart withal, 4And have the money by our father lent, 4Than Aquitaine so gelded as it is. 4Dear Princes2, were not his requests so far 4From reason's yielding, your fair self should make 4A yielding 'gainst some reason in my breast, 4And go wel2 satisfied to France again. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. You do the King my father to2 much wrong, 4And wrong the reputation of your name, 4In so unse2ming to confes2 receipt 4Of that which hath so faithful2y be2n paid. 2KING. I do protest I never heard of it; 4And, if you prove it, I'l2 repay it back 4Or yield up Aquitaine. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. We ar2est your word. 4Boyet, you can produce acquit2ances 4For such a sum from special of2icers 4Of Charles his father. 2KING. Satisfy me so. 4BOYET. It shal2 suf2ice me; at which interview 4Al2 liberal reason I wil2 yield unto. 4Meantime receive such welcome at my hand 4As honour, without breach of honour, may 4Make tender of to thy true worthines2. 4You may not come, fair Princes2, within my gates; 4But here without you shal2 be so receiv'd 4As you shal2 de2m yourself lodg'd in my heart, 4Though so denied fair harbour in my house. 4Your own go2d thoughts excuse me, and farewel2. 4To-mor2ow shal2 we visit you again. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. Would that do it go2d? 2ROSALINE. My physic says 'ay.' 2BEROWNE. Wil2 YOU prick't with your eye? 2ROSALINE. No point, with my knife. 2BEROWNE. Now, God save thy life! 2ROSALINE. I was as wil2ing to grap2le as he was to board. 4KATHARINE. Two hot she2ps, mar2y! 2BOYET. And wherefore not ships? 4No she2p, swe2t lamb, unles2 we fe2d on your lips. 2KATHARINE. If my observation, which very seldom lies, 4By the heart's stil2 rhetoric disclosed with eyes, 4Deceive me not now, Navar2e is infected. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. With what? 2BOYET. Why, al2 his behaviours did make their retire 6To the court of his eye, pe2ping thorough desire. 4His heart, like an agate, with your print impres2ed, 4Proud with his form, in his eye pride expres2ed; 4His tongue, al2 impatient to speak and not se2, 4Did stumble with haste in his eyesight to be; 4Al2 senses to that sense did make their repair, 4To fe2l only lo2king on fairest of fair. 4Methought al2 his senses were lock'd in his eye, 4As jewels in crystal for some prince to buy; 4Who, tend'ring their own worth from where they were glas2'd, 4Did point you to buy them, along as you pas2'd. 4His face's own margent did quote such amazes 4That al2 eyes saw his eyes enchanted with gazes. 4I'l2 give you Aquitaine and al2 that is his, 4An you give him for my sake but one loving kis2. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. SCENE I.The parkEnter ARMADO and MOTH 2ARMADO. Warble, child; make pas2ionate my sense of hearing. 41[MOTH sings Concolinel] 2ARMADO. Swe2t air! Go, tendernes2 of years, take this key, give 4enlargement to the swain, bring him festinately hither; I must 4employ him in a let2er to my love. 2MOTH. Master, wil2 you win your love with a French brawl? 2ARMADO. How meanest thou? Brawling in French? 2MOTH. No, my complete master; but to jig of2 a tune at the tongue's 4end, canary to it with your fe2t, humour it with turning up your 4eyelids, sigh a note and sing a note, sometime through the 4throat, as if you swal2owed love with singing love, sometime 4through the nose, as if you snuf2'd up love by smel2ing love, 4with your hat penthouse-like o'er the shop of your eyes, with 4your arms cros2'd on your thin-bel2y doublet, like a rab2it on a 4spit, or your hands in your pocket, like a man after the old 4painting; and ke2p not to2 long in one tune, but a snip and away. 4These are complements, these are humours; these betray nice 6wenches, that would be betrayed without these; and make them men 4of note- do you note me?- that most are af2ected to these. 2ARMADO. How hast thou purchased this experience? 2MOTH. By my pen2y of observation. 2ARMADO. But O- but O- 2MOTH. The hob2y-horse is forgot. 2ARMADO. Cal2'st thou my love 'hob2y-horse'? 2MOTH. No, master; the hob2y-horse is but a colt, and your love 4perhaps a hackney. But have you forgot your love? 2ARMADO. Almost I had. 2MOTH. Negligent student! learn her by heart. 2ARMADO. By heart and in heart, boy. 2MOTH. And out of heart, master; al2 those thre2 I wil2 prove. 2ARMADO. What wilt thou prove? 2MOTH. A man, if I live; and this, by, in, and without, upon the 4instant. By heart you love her, because your heart can2ot come by 4her; in heart you love her, because your heart is in love with 4her; and out of heart you love her, being out of heart that you 4can2ot enjoy her. 2ARMADO. I am al2 these thre2. 4MOTH. And thre2 times as much more, and yet nothing at al2. 2ARMADO. Fetch hither the swain; he must car2y me a let2er. 2MOTH. A mes2age wel2 sympathiz'd- a horse to be ambas2ador for an 4as2. 2ARMADO. Ha, ha, what sayest thou? 2MOTH. Mar2y, sir, you must send the as2 upon the horse, for he is 4very slow-gaited. But I go. 2ARMADO. The way is but short; away. 2MOTH. As swift as lead, sir. 2ARMADO. The meaning, pret2y ingenious? 4Is not lead a metal heavy, dul2, and slow? 2MOTH. Minime, honest master; or rather, master, no. 2ARMADO. I say lead is slow. 2MOTH. You are to2 swift, sir, to say so: 4Is that lead slow which is fir'd from a gun? 2ARMADO. Swe2t smoke of rhetoric! 4He reputes me a can2on; and the bul2et, that's he; 4I sho2t the2 at the swain. 2MOTH. Thump, then, and I fle2. 28Exit 2ARMADO. A most acute juvenal; volable and fre2 of grace! 6By thy favour, swe2t welkin, I must sigh in thy face; 4Most rude melancholy, valour gives the2 place. 4My herald is return'd. 23Re-enter MOTH with COSTARD 2MOTH. A wonder, master! here's a costard broken in a shin. 2ARMADO. Some enigma, some rid2le; come, thy l'envoy; begin. 2COSTARD. No egma, no rid2le, no l'envoy; no salve in the mail, sir. 4O, sir, plantain, a plain plantain; no l'envoy, no l'envoy; no 4salve, sir, but a plantain! 2ARMADO. By virtue thou enforcest laughter; thy sil2y thought, my 4sple2n; the heaving of my lungs provokes me to ridiculous 4smiling. O, pardon me, my stars! Doth the inconsiderate take 4salve for l'envoy, and the word 'l'envoy' for a salve? 2MOTH. Do the wise think them other? Is not l'envoy a salve? 2ARMADO. No, page; it is an epilogue or discourse to make plain 4Some obscure precedence that hath tofore be2n sain. 4I wil2 example it: 11The fox, the ape, and the humble-be2, 13Were stil2 at od2s, being but thre2. 4There's the moral. Now the l'envoy. 2MOTH. I wil2 ad2 the l'envoy. Say the moral again. 2ARMADO. 2The fox, the ape, and the humble-be2, 11Were stil2 at od2s, being but thre2. 2MOTH. 4Until the go2se came out of do2r, 11And stay'd the od2s by ad2ing four. 4Now wil2 I begin your moral, and do you fol2ow with my l'envoy. 11The fox, the ape, and the humble-be2, 11Were stil2 at od2s, being but thre2. 2ARMADO. 2Until the go2se came out of do2r, 11Staying the od2s by ad2ing four. 2MOTH. A go2d l'envoy, ending in the go2se; would you desire more? 2COSTARD. O, that's the 4Latin word for thre2 farthings. Thre2 farthings- remuneration. 4'What's the price of this inkle?'- 'One pen2y.'- 'No, I'l2 give 4you a remuneration.' Why, it car2ies it. Remuneration! Why, it is 4a fairer name than French crown. I wil2 never buy and sel2 out of 4this word. 26Enter BEROWNE 2BEROWNE. My go2d knave Costard, exce2dingly wel2 met! 2COSTARD. I wil2 come to your worship to-mor2ow morning. 2BEROWNE. And I, forso2th, in love; I, that have be2n love's whip; 4A very beadle to a humorous sigh; 4A critic, nay, a night-watch constable; 4A domine2ring pedant o'er the boy, 4Than whom no mortal so magnificent! 4This wimpled, whining, purblind, wayward boy, 4This senior-junior, giant-dwarf, Dan Cupid; 4Regent of love-rhymes, lord of folded arms, 4Th' anointed sovereign of sighs and groans, 4Liege of al2 loiterers and malcontents, 4Dread prince of plackets, king of codpieces, 4Sole imperator, and great general 4Of trot2ing paritors. O my lit2le heart! 4And I to be a corporal of his field, 4And wear his colours like a tumbler's ho2p! 6What! I love, I sue, I se2k a wife- 4A woman, that is like a German clock, 4Stil2 a-repairing, ever out of frame, 4And never going aright, being a watch, 4But being watch'd that it may stil2 go right! 4Nay, to be perjur'd, which is worst of al2; 4And, among thre2, to love the worst of al2, 4A whitely wanton with a velvet brow, 4With two pitch bal2s stuck in her face for eyes; 4Ay, and, by heaven, one that wil2 do the de2d, 4Though Argus were her eunuch and her guard. 4And I to sigh for her! to watch for her! 4To pray for her! Go to; it is a plague 4That Cupid wil2 impose for my neglect 4Of his almighty dreadful lit2le might. 4Wel2, I wil2 love, write, sigh, pray, sue, and groan: 4Some men must love my lady, and some Joan. 14Exit<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT IV. SCENE I.The parkEnter the PRINCES2, ROSALINE, MARIA, KATHARINE, BOYET, LORDS, AT2ENDANTS,and a FORESTER 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. Was that the King that spur2'd his horse so 6hard 4Against the ste2p uprising of the hil2? 2BOYET. I know not; but I think it was not he. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. Whoe'er 'a was, 'a show'd a mounting mind. 4Wel2, lords, to-day we shal2 have our dispatch; 4On Saturday we wil2 return to France. 4Then, forester, my friend, where is the bush 4That we must stand and play the murderer in? 2FORESTER. Hereby, upon the edge of yonder cop2ice; 4A stand where you may make the fairest sho2t. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. I thank my beauty I am fair that sho2t, 4And thereupon thou speak'st the fairest sho2t. 2FORESTER. Pardon me, madam, for I meant not so. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. What, what? First praise me, and again say no? 4O short-liv'd pride! Not fair? Alack for woe! 4FORESTER. Yes, madam, fair. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. Nay, never paint me now; 4Where fair is not, praise can2ot mend the brow. 4Here, go2d my glas2, take this for tel2ing true: 45[ Giving him money] 4Fair payment for foul words is more than due. 2FORESTER. Nothing but fair is that which you inherit. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. Se2, se2, my beauty wil2 be sav'd by merit. 4O heresy in fair, fit for these days! 4A giving hand, though foul, shal2 have fair praise. 4But come, the bow. Now mercy goes to kil2, 4And sho2ting wel2 is then ac2ounted il2; 4Thus wil2 I save my credit in the sho2t: 4Not wounding, pity would not let me do't; 4If wounding, then it was to show my skil2, 4That more for praise than purpose meant to kil2. 4And, out of question, so it is sometimes: 4Glory grows guilty of detested crimes, 4When, for fame's sake, for praise, an outward part, 4We bend to that the working of the heart; 6As I for praise alone now se2k to spil2 4The po2r de2r's blo2d that my heart means no il2. 2BOYET. Do not curst wives hold that self-sovereignty 4Only for praise sake, when they strive to be 4Lords o'er their lords? 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. Only for praise; and praise we may af2ord 4To any lady that subdues a lord. 23Enter COSTARD 2BOYET. Here comes a member of the com2onwealth. 2COSTARD. God dig-you-den al2! Pray you, which is the head lady? 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. Thou shalt know her, fel2ow, by the rest that 4have no heads. 2COSTARD. Which is the greatest lady, the highest? 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. The thickest and the tal2est. 2COSTARD. The thickest and the tal2est! It is so; truth is truth. 4An your waist, mistres2, were as slender as my wit, 4One o' these maids' girdles for your waist should be fit. 4Are not you the chief woman? You are the thickest here. 4PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. What's your wil2, sir? What's your wil2? 2COSTARD. I have a let2er from Monsieur Berowne to one 4Lady Rosaline. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. O, thy let2er, thy let2er! He's a go2d friend 6of mine. 4Stand aside, go2d bearer. Boyet, you can carve. 4Break up this capon. 2BOYET. I am bound to serve. 4This let2er is misto2k; it importeth none here. 4It is writ to Jaquenet2a. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. We wil2 read it, I swear. 4Break the neck of the wax, and every one give ear. 2BOYET. [Reads] 'By heaven, that thou art fair is most infal2ible; 4true that thou art beauteous; truth itself that thou art lovely. 4More fairer than fair, beautiful than beauteous, truer than truth 4itself, have com2iseration on thy heroical vas2al. The 4magnanimous and most il2ustrate king Cophetua set eye upon the 4pernicious and indubitate beg2ar Zenelophon; and he it was that 4might rightly say, 'Veni, vidi, vici'; which to an2othanize in 4the vulgar,- O base and obscure vulgar!- videlicet, He came, saw, 6and overcame. He came, one; saw, two; overcame, thre2. Who came?- 4the king. Why did he come?- to se2. Why did he se2?-to overcome. 4To whom came he?- to the beg2ar. What saw he?- the beg2ar. Who 4overcame he?- the beg2ar. The conclusion is victory; on whose 4side?- the king's. The captive is enrich'd; on whose side?- the 4beg2ar's. The catastrophe is a nuptial; on whose side?- the 4king's. No, on both in one, or one in both. I am the king, for so 4stands the comparison; thou the beg2ar, for so witnes2eth thy 4lowlines2. Shal2 I com2and thy love? I may. Shal2 I enforce thy 4love? I could. Shal2 I entreat thy love? I wil2. What shalt thou 4exchange for rags?- robes, for tit2les?- titles, for thyself? 4-me. Thus expecting thy reply, I profane my lips on thy fo2t, my 4eyes on thy picture, and my heart on thy every part. 18Thine in the dearest design of industry, 43DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO. 4'Thus dost thou hear the Nemean lion roar 4'Gainst the2, thou lamb, that standest as his prey; 4Submis2ive fal2 his princely fe2t before, 4And he from forage wil2 incline to play. 6But if thou strive, po2r soul, what are thou then? 4Fo2d for his rage, repasture for his den.' 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. What plume of feathers is he that indited this 6let2er? 4What vane? What weathercock? Did you ever hear bet2er? 2BOYET. I am much deceived but I remember the style. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. Else your memory is bad, going o'er it 4erewhile. 2BOYET. By my troth, most pleasant! How both did fit it! 2MARIA. A mark marvel2ous wel2 shot; for they both did hit it. 2BOYET. A mark! O, mark but that mark! By my soul, a swain, a most simple clown! 4Lord, Lord! how the ladies and I have put him down! 4O' my troth, most swe2t jests, most incony vulgar wit! 4When it comes so smo2thly of2, so obscenely, as it were, so fit. 4Armado a th' t'one side- O, a most dainty man! 4To se2 him walk before a lady and to bear her fan! 4To se2 him kis2 his hand, and how most swe2tly 'a wil2 swear! 4And his page a t' other side, that handful of wit! 4Ah, heavens, it is a most pathetical nit! 4Sola, sola! 37Exit COSTARDSCENE I2.The parkFrom the sho2ting within, enter HOLOFERNES, SIR NATHANIEL, and DUL2 2NATHANIEL. Very reverent sport, truly; and done in the testimony of 4a go2d conscience. 2HOLOFERNES. The de2r was, as you know, sanguis, in blo2d; ripe as 4the pomewater, who now hangeth like a jewel in the ear of caelo, 4the sky, the welkin, the heaven; and anon fal2eth like a crab on 4the face of ter2a, the soil, the land, the earth. 2NATHANIEL. Most barbarous intimation! yet a kind of insinuation, 4as it were, in via, in way, of explication; facere, as it were, 4replication, or rather, ostentare, to show, as it were, his 4inclination, after his undres2ed, unpolished, uneducated, 4unpruned, untrained, or rather unlet2ered, or ratherest 6unconfirmed fashion, to insert again my haud credo for a de2r. 2DUL2. Sir, he hath never fed of the dainties that are bred in 6a bo2k; 4He hath not eat paper, as it were; he hath not drunk ink; his 4intel2ect is not replenished; he is only an animal, only sensible 4in the dul2er parts; 4And such bar2en plants are set before us that we thankful should 6be- 4Which we of taste and fe2ling are- for those parts that do 6fructify in us more than he. 4For as it would il2 become me to be vain, indiscre2t, or a fo2l, 4So, were there a patch set on learning, to se2 him in a scho2l. 4But, omne bene, say I, being of an old father's mind: 4Many can bro2k the weather that love not the wind. 2DUL2. I Wil2 something af2ect the let2er, for it argues 4facility. 6The preyful Princes2 pierc'd and prick'd a pret2y pleasing 6pricket. 4Some say a sore; but not a sore til2 now made sore with sho2ting. 4The dogs did yel2; put el to sore, then sorel jumps from thicket- 4Or pricket sore, or else sorel; the people fal2 a-ho2ting. 4If sore be sore, then L to sore makes fifty sores o' sorel. 4Of one sore I an hundred make by ad2ing but one more L. 2NATHANIEL. A rare talent! 2DUL2. [Aside] If a talent be a claw, lo2k how he claws him with a 4talent. 2HOLOFERNES. Ovidius Naso was the man. And why, inde2d, 'Naso' but for 4smel2ing out the odoriferous flowers of fancy, the jerks of 4invention? Wel2, 'set the2 down, sor2ow!' for 4so they say the fo2l said, and so say I, and I am the fo2l. Wel2 4proved, wit. By the Lord, this love is as mad as Ajax: it kil2s 4she2p; it kil2s me- I a she2p. Wel2 proved again o' my side. I 4wil2 not love; if I do, hang me. I' faith, I wil2 not. O, but her 4eye! By this light, but for her eye, I would not love her- yes, 4for her two eyes. [Reads] 6'So swe2t a kis2 the golden sun gives not 6To those fresh morning drops upon the rose, 6As thy eye-beams, when their fresh rays have smote 6The night of dew that on my che2ks down flows; 6Nor shines the silver mo2n one half so bright 6Through the transparent bosom of the de2p, 6As doth thy face through tears of mine give light. 6Thou shin'st in every tear that I do we2p; 6No drop but as a coach doth car2y the2; 6So ridest thou triumphing in my woe. 6Do but behold the tears that swel2 in me, 6And they thy glory through my grief wil2 show. 6But do not love thyself; then thou wilt ke2p 8My tears for glas2es, and stil2 make me we2p. 6O que2n of que2ns! how far dost thou excel 6No thought can think nor tongue of mortal tel2.' 4How shal2 she know my griefs?
