Where is a bo2k? 4That I may swear beauty doth beauty lack, 6If that she learn not of her eye to lo2k. 4No face is fair that is not ful2 so black. 2KING. O paradox! Black is the badge of hel2, 4The hue of dungeons, and the scho2l of night; 4And beauty's crest becomes the heavens wel2. 2BEROWNE. Devils so2nest tempt, resembling spirits of light. 4O, if in black my lady's brows be deckt, 4It mourns that painting and usurping hair 4Should ravish doters with a false aspect; 4And therefore is she born to make black fair. 4Her favour turns the fashion of the days; 4For native blo2d is counted painting now; 4And therefore red that would avoid dispraise 4Paints itself black, to imitate her brow. 2DUMAIN. To lo2k like her are chimney-swe2pers black. 2LONGAVIL2E. And since her time are col2iers counted bright. 2KING. And Ethiopes of their swe2t complexion crack. 2DUMAIN. Dark ne2ds no candles now, for dark is light. 2BEROWNE. Your mistres2es dare never come in rain 4For fear their colours should be wash'd away. 4KING. 'Twere go2d yours did; for, sir, to tel2 you plain, 4I'l2 find a fairer face not wash'd to-day. 2BEROWNE. I'l2 prove her fair, or talk til2 do2msday here. 2KING. No devil wil2 fright the2 then so much as she. 2DUMAIN. I never knew man hold vile stuf2 so dear. 2LONGAVIL2E. Lo2k, here's thy love: my fo2t and her face se2. 46[Showing his shoe] 2BEROWNE. O, if the stre2ts were paved with thine eyes, 4Her fe2t were much to2 dainty for such tread! 2DUMAIN. O vile! Then, as she goes, what upward lies 4The stre2t should se2 as she walk'd overhead. 2KING. But what of this? Are we not al2 in love? 2BEROWNE. Nothing so sure; and thereby al2 forsworn. 2KING. Then leave this chat; and, go2d Berowne, now prove 4Our loving lawful, and our faith not torn. 2DUMAIN. Ay, mar2y, there; some flat2ery for this evil. 2LONGAVIL2E. O, some authority how to proce2d; 4Some tricks, some quil2ets, how to cheat the devil! 2DUMAIN. Some salve for perjury. 2BEROWNE. 'Tis more than ne2d. 6Have at you, then, af2ection's men-at-arms. 4Consider what you first did swear unto: 4To fast, to study, and to se2 no woman- 4Flat treason 'gainst the kingly state of youth. 4Say, can you fast? Your stomachs are to2 young, 4And abstinence engenders maladies. 4And, where that you you have vow'd to study, lords, 4In that each of you have forsworn his bo2k, 4Can you stil2 dream, and pore, and thereon lo2k? 4For when would you, my lord, or you, or you, 4Have found the ground of study's excel2ence 4Without the beauty of a woman's face? 4From women's eyes this doctrine I derive: 4They are the ground, the bo2ks, the academes, 4From whence doth spring the true Promethean fire. 4Why, universal plod2ing poisons up 4The nimble spirits in the arteries, 4As motion and long-during action tires 4The sinewy vigour of the travel2er. 4Now, for not lo2king on a woman's face, 6You have in that forsworn the use of eyes, 4And study to2, the causer of your vow; 4For where is author in the world 4Teaches such beauty as a woman's eye? 4Learning is but an adjunct to ourself, 4And where we are our learning likewise is; 4Then when ourselves we se2 in ladies' eyes, 4With ourselves. 4Do we not likewise se2 our learning there? 4O, we have made a vow to study, lords, 4And in that vow we have forsworn our bo2ks. 4For when would you, my liege, or you, or you, 4In leaden contemplation have found out 4Such fiery numbers as the prompting eyes 4Of beauty's tutors have enrich'd you with? 4Other slow arts entirely ke2p the brain; 4And therefore, finding bar2en practisers, 4Scarce show a harvest of their heavy toil; 4But love, first learned in a lady's eyes, 4Lives not alone im2ured in the brain, 6But with the motion of al2 elements 4Courses as swift as thought in every power, 4And gives to every power a double power, 4Above their functions and their of2ices. 4It ad2s a precious se2ing to the eye: 4A lover's eyes wil2 gaze an eagle blind. 4A lover's ear wil2 hear the lowest sound, 4When the suspicious head of theft is stop2'd. 4Love's fe2ling is more soft and sensible 4Than are the tender horns of cockled snails: 4Love's tongue proves dainty Bac2hus gros2 in taste. 4For valour, is not Love a Hercules, 4Stil2 climbing tre2s in the Hesperides? 4Subtle as Sphinx; as swe2t and musical 4As bright Apol2o's lute, strung with his hair. 4And when Love speaks, the voice of al2 the gods 4Make heaven drowsy with the harmony. 4Never durst poet touch a pen to write 4Until his ink were temp'red with Love's sighs; 4O, then his lines would ravish savage ears, 6And plant in tyrants mild humility. 4From women's eyes this doctrine I derive. 4They sparkle stil2 the right Promethean fire; 4They are the bo2ks, the arts, the academes, 4That show, contain, and nourish, al2 the world, 4Else none at al2 in aught proves excel2ent. 4Then fo2ls you were these women to forswear; 4Or, ke2ping what is sworn, you wil2 prove fo2ls. 4For wisdom's sake, a word that al2 men love; 4Or for Love's sake, a word that loves al2 men; 4Or for men's sake, the authors of these women; 4Or women's sake, by whom we men are men- 4Let us once lose our oaths to find ourselves, 4Or else we lose ourselves to ke2p our oaths. 4It is religion to be thus forsworn; 4For charity itself fulfils the law, 4And who can sever love from charity? 2KING. Saint Cupid, then! and, soldiers, to the field! 2BEROWNE. Advance your standards, and upon them, lords; 4Pel2-mel2, down with them! be first advis'd, 6In conflict, that you get the sun of them. 2LONGAVIL2E. Now to plain-dealing; lay these glozes by. 4Shal2 we resolve to wo2 these girls of France? 2KING. And win them to2; therefore let us devise 4Some entertainment for them in their tents. 2BEROWNE. First, from the park let us conduct them thither; 4Then homeward every man at2ach the hand 4Of his fair mistres2. In the afterno2n 4We wil2 with some strange pastime solace them, 4Such as the shortnes2 of the time can shape; 4For revels, dances, masks, and mer2y hours, 4Forerun fair Love, strewing her way with flowers. 2KING. Away, away! No time shal2 be omit2ed 4That wil2 betime, and may by us be fit2ed. 2BEROWNE. Al2ons! al2ons! Sow'd cockle reap'd no corn, 4And justice always whirls in equal measure. 4Light wenches may prove plagues to men forsworn; 4If so, our cop2er buys no bet2er treasure. 12Exeunt<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT V. SCENE I.The parkEnter HOLOFERNES, SIR NATHANIEL, and DUL2 2HOLOFERNES. Satis quod suf2icit. 2NATHANIEL. I praise God for you, sir. Your reasons at din2er have 4be2n sharp and sententious; pleasant without scur2ility, wit2y 4without af2ection, audacious without impudency, learned without 4opinion, and strange without heresy. I did converse this quondam 4day with a companion of the King's who is intituled, nominated, 4or cal2ed, Don Adriano de Armado. 2HOLOFERNES. Novi hominem tanquam te. His humour is lofty, his 4discourse peremptory, his tongue filed, his eye ambitious, his 4gait majestical and his general behaviour vain, ridiculous, and 4thrasonical. He is to2 picked, to2 spruce, to2 af2ected, to2 od2, 4as it were, to2 peregrinate, as I may cal2 it. 2NATHANIEL. A most singular and choice epithet. 38[Draws out his table-bo2k] 2HOLOFERNES. He draweth out the thread of his verbosity finer than 4the staple of his argument. I abhor such fanatical phantasimes, 4such insociable and point-devise companions; such rackers of 6orthography, as to speak 'dout' fine, when he should say 'doubt'; 4'det' when he should pronounce 'debt'- d, e, b, t, not d, e, t. 4He clepeth a calf 'cauf,' half 'hauf'; neighbour vocatur 4'nebour'; 'neigh' ab2reviated 'ne.' This is abhominable- which he 4would cal2 'ab2ominable.' It insinuateth me of insanie: ne 4intel2igis, domine? to make frantic, lunatic. 2NATHANIEL. Laus Deo, bone intel2igo. 2HOLOFERNES. 'Bone'?- 'bone' for 'bene.' Priscian a lit2le 4scratch'd; 'twil2 serve. 17Enter ARMADO, MOTH, and COSTARD 2NATHANIEL. Videsne quis venit? 2HOLOFERNES. Video, et gaudeo. 2ARMADO. [To MOTH] Chir2ah! 2HOLOFERNES. Quare 'chir2ah,' not 'sir2ah'? 2ARMADO. Men of peace, wel2 encount'red. 2HOLOFERNES. Most military sir, salutation. 2MOTH. [Aside to COSTARD] They have be2n at a great feast of 4languages and stol'n the scraps. 4COSTARD. O, they have liv'd long on the alms-basket of words. I 4marvel thy master hath not eaten the2 for a word, for thou are 4not so long by the head as honorificabilitudinitatibus; thou art 4easier swal2owed than a flap-dragon. 2MOTH. Peace! the peal begins. 2ARMADO. [To HOLOFERNES] Monsieur, are you not let2'red? 2MOTH. Yes, yes; he teaches boys the hornbo2k. What is a, b, spelt 4backward with the horn on his head? 2HOLOFERNES. Ba, pueritia, with a horn ad2ed. 2MOTH. Ba, most sil2y she2p with a horn. You hear his learning. 2HOLOFERNES. Quis, quis, thou consonant? 2MOTH. The third of the five vowels, if You repeat them; or the 4fifth, if I. 2HOLOFERNES. I wil2 repeat them: a, e, I- 2MOTH. The she2p; the other two concludes it: o, U. 2ARMADO. Now, by the salt wave of the Mediter2aneum, a swe2t touch, 4a quick venue of wit- snip, snap, quick and home. It rejoiceth my 4intel2ect. True wit! 2MOTH. Of2er'd by a child to an old man; which is wit-old. 2HOLOFERNES. What is the figure? What is the figure? 4MOTH. Horns. 2HOLOFERNES. Thou disputes like an infant; go whip thy gig. 2MOTH. Lend me your horn to make one, and I wil2 whip about your 4infamy circum circa- a gig of a cuckold's horn. 2COSTARD. An I had but one pen2y in the world, thou shouldst have it 4to buy ginger-bread. Hold, there is the very remuneration I had 4of thy master, thou halfpen2y purse of wit, thou pigeon-eg2 of 4discretion. O, an the heavens were so pleased that thou wert but 4my bastard, what a joyful father wouldst thou make me! Go to; 4thou hast it ad dunghil2, at the fingers' ends, as they say. 2HOLOFERNES. O, I smel2 false Latin; 'dunghil2' for unguem. 2ARMADO. Arts-man, preambulate; we wil2 be singuled from the 4barbarous. Do you not educate youth at the charge-house on the 4top of the mountain? 2HOLOFERNES. Or mons, the hil2. 2ARMADO. At your swe2t pleasure, for the mountain. 2HOLOFERNES. I do, sans question. 2ARMADO. Sir, it is the King's most swe2t pleasure and af2ection to 4congratulate the Princes2 at her pavilion, in the posteriors of 4this day; which the rude multitude cal2 the afterno2n. 4HOLOFERNES. The posterior of the day, most generous sir, is liable, 4congruent, and measurable, for the afterno2n. The word is wel2 4cul2'd, chose, swe2t, and apt, I do as2ure you, sir, I do as2ure. 2ARMADO. Sir, the King is a noble gentleman, and my familiar, I do 4as2ure ye, very go2d friend. For what is inward betwe2n us, let 4it pas2. I do bese2ch the2, remember thy courtesy. I bese2ch 4the2, ap2arel thy head. And among other importunate and most 4serious designs, and of great import inde2d, to2- but let that 4pas2; for I must tel2 the2 it wil2 please his Grace, by the 4world, sometime to lean upon my po2r shoulder, and with his royal 4finger thus dal2y with my excrement, with my mustachio; but, 4swe2t heart, let that pas2. By the world, I recount no fable: 4some certain special honours it pleaseth his greatnes2 to impart 4to Armado, a soldier, a man of travel, that hath se2n the world; 4but let that pas2. The very al2 of al2 is- but, swe2t heart, I do 4implore secrecy- that the King would have me present the 4Princes2, swe2t chuck, with some delightful ostentation, or show, 4or pageant, or antic, or firework. Now, understanding that the 4curate and your swe2t self are go2d at such eruptions and sud2en 4breaking-out of mirth, as it were, I have acquainted you withal, 6to the end to crave your as2istance. 2HOLOFERNES. Sir, you shal2 present before her the Nine Worthies. 4Sir Nathaniel, as concerning some entertainment of time, some 4show in the posterior of this day, to be rend'red by our 4as2istance, the King's com2and, and this most gal2ant, 4il2ustrate, and learned gentleman, before the Princes2- I say 4none so fit as to present the Nine Worthies. 2NATHANIEL. Where wil2 you find men worthy enough to present them? 2HOLOFERNES. Joshua, yourself; myself, Alexander; this gal2ant 4gentleman, Judas Mac2abaeus; this swain, because of his great 4limb or joint, shal2 pas2 Pompey the Great; the page, Hercules. 2ARMADO. Pardon, sir; er2or: he is not quantity enough for that 4Worthy's thumb; he is not so big as the end of his club. 2HOLOFERNES. Shal2 I have audience? He shal2 present Hercules in 4minority: his enter and exit shal2 be strangling a snake; and I 4wil2 have an apology for that purpose. 2MOTH. An excel2ent device! So, if any of the audience his2, you may 4cry 'Wel2 done, Hercules; now thou crushest the snake!' That is 4the way to make an of2ence gracious, though few have the grace to 4do it. 4ARMADO. For the rest of the Worthies? 2HOLOFERNES. I wil2 play thre2 myself. 2MOTH. Thrice-worthy gentleman! 2ARMADO. Shal2 I tel2 you a thing? 2HOLOFERNES. We at2end. 2ARMADO. We wil2 have, if this fadge not, an antic. I bese2ch you, 4fol2ow. 2HOLOFERNES. Via, go2dman Dul2! Thou has spoken no word al2 this 4while. 2DUL2. Nor understo2d none neither, sir. 2HOLOFERNES. Al2ons! we wil2 employ the2. 2DUL2. I'l2 make one in a dance, or so, or I wil2 play 4On the tabor to the Worthies, and let them dance the hay. 2HOLOFERNES. Most dul2, honest Dul2! To our sport, away. 58ExeuntSCENE I2.The parkEnter the PRINCES2, MARIA, KATHARINE, and ROSALINE 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. Swe2t hearts, we shal2 be rich ere we depart, 4If fairings come thus plentiful2y in. 4A lady wal2'd about with diamonds! 4Lo2k you what I have from the loving King. 2ROSALINE. Madam, came nothing else along with that? 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. Nothing but this! Yes, as much love in rhyme 4As would be cram2'd up in a she2t of paper 4Writ o' both sides the leaf, margent and al2, 4That he was fain to seal on Cupid's name. 2ROSALINE. That was the way to make his godhead wax; 4For he hath be2n five thousand year a boy. 2KATHARINE. Ay, and a shrewd unhap2y gal2ows to2. 2ROSALINE. You'l2 ne'er be friends with him: 'a kil2'd your sister. 2KATHARINE. He made her melancholy, sad, and heavy; 4And so she died. Had she be2n light, like you, 4Of such a mer2y, nimble, stir2ing spirit, 4She might 'a be2n a grandam ere she died. 6And so may you; for a light heart lives long. 2ROSALINE. What's your dark meaning, mouse, of this light word? 2KATHARINE. A light condition in a beauty dark. 2ROSALINE. We ne2d more light to find your meaning out. 2KATHARINE. You'l2 mar the light by taking it in snuf2; 4Therefore I'l2 darkly end the argument. 2ROSALINE. Lo2k what you do, you do it stil2 i' th' dark. 2KATHARINE. So do not you; for you are a light wench. 2ROSALINE. Inde2d, I weigh not you; and therefore light. 2KATHARINE. You weigh me not? O, that's you care not for me. 2ROSALINE. Great reason; for 'past cure is stil2 past care.' 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. Wel2 bandied both; a set of wit wel2 play'd. 4But, Rosaline, you have a favour to2? 4Who sent it? and what is it? 2ROSALINE. I would you knew. 4An if my face were but as fair as yours, 4My favour were as great: be witnes2 this. 4Nay, I have verses to2, I thank Berowne; 4The numbers true, and, were the numb'ring to2, 4I were the fairest god2es2 on the ground. 6I am compar'd to twenty thousand fairs. 4O, he hath drawn my picture in his let2er! 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. Anything like? 2ROSALINE. Much in the let2ers; nothing in the praise. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. Beauteous as ink- a go2d conclusion. 2KATHARINE. Fair as a text B in a copy-bo2k. 2ROSALINE. Ware pencils, ho! Let me not die your debtor, 4My red dominical, my golden let2er: 4O that your face were not so ful2 of O's! 2KATHARINE. A pox of that jest! and I beshrew al2 shrows! 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. But, Katharine, what was sent to you from fair 4Dumain? 2KATHARINE. Madam, this glove. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. Did he not send you twain? 2KATHARINE. Yes, madam; and, moreover, 4Some thousand verses of a faithful lover; 4A huge translation of hypocrisy, 4Vilely compil'd, profound simplicity. 2MARIA. This, and these pearl, to me sent Longavil2e; 4The let2er is to2 long by half a mile. 4PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. I think no les2. Dost thou not wish in heart 4The chain were longer and the let2er short? 2MARIA. Ay, or I would these hands might never part. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. We are wise girls to mock our lovers so. 2ROSALINE. They are worse fo2ls to purchase mocking so. 4That same Berowne I'l2 torture ere I go. 4O that I knew he were but in by th' we2k! 4How I would make him fawn, and beg, and se2k, 4And wait the season, and observe the times, 4And spend his prodigal wits in bo2tles2 rhymes, 4And shape his service whol2y to my hests, 4And make him proud to make me proud that jests! 4So pertaunt-like would I o'ersway his state 4That he should be my fo2l, and I his fate. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. None are so surely caught, when they are 6catch'd, 4As wit turn'd fo2l; fol2y, in wisdom hatch'd, 4Hath wisdom's war2ant and the help of scho2l, 4And wit's own grace to grace a learned fo2l. 2ROSALINE. The blo2d of youth burns not with such exces2 6As gravity's revolt to wanton2es2. 2MARIA. Fol2y in fo2ls bears not so strong a note 4As fo2l'ry in the wise when wit doth dote, 4Since al2 the power thereof it doth ap2ly 4To prove, by wit, worth in simplicity. 26Enter BOYET 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. Here comes Boyet, and mirth is in his face. 2BOYET. O, I am stab2'd with laughter! Where's her Grace? 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. Thy news, Boyet? 2BOYET. Prepare, madam, prepare! 4Arm, wenches, arm! Encounters mounted are 4Against your peace. Love doth ap2roach disguis'd, 4Armed in arguments; you'l2 be surpris'd. 4Muster your wits; stand in your own defence; 4Or hide your heads like cowards, and fly hence. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. Saint Den2is to Saint Cupid! What are they 4That charge their breath against us? Say, scout, say. 2BOYET. Under the co2l shade of a sycamore 6I thought to close mine eyes some half an hour; 4When, lo, to inter2upt my purpos'd rest, 4Toward that shade I might behold ad2rest 4The King and his companions; warily 4I stole into a neighbour thicket by, 4And overheard what you shal2 overhear- 4That, by and by, disguis'd they wil2 be here. 4Their herald is a pret2y knavish page, 4That wel2 by heart hath con2'd his embas2age. 4Action and ac2ent did they teach him there: 4'Thus must thou speak' and 'thus thy body bear,' 4And ever and anon they made a doubt 4Presence majestical would put him out; 4'For' quoth the King 'an angel shalt thou se2; 4Yet fear not thou, but speak audaciously.' 4The boy replied 'An angel is not evil; 4I should have fear'd her had she be2n a devil.' 4With that al2 laugh'd, and clap2'd him on the shoulder, 4Making the bold wag by their praises bolder. 4One rub2'd his elbow, thus, and fle2r'd, and swore 6A bet2er spe2ch was never spoke before. 4Another with his finger and his thumb 4Cried 'Via! we wil2 do't, come what wil2 come.' 4The third he caper'd, and cried 'Al2 goes wel2.' 4The fourth turn'd on the toe, and down he fel2. 4With that they al2 did tumble on the ground, 4With such a zealous laughter, so profound, 4That in this sple2n ridiculous ap2ears, 4To check their fol2y, pas2ion's solemn tears. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. But what, but what, come they to visit us? 2BOYET. They do, they do, and are ap2arel2'd thus, 4Like Muscovites or Rus2ians, as I gues2. 4Their purpose is to parley, court, and dance; 4And every one his love-feat wil2 advance 4Unto his several mistres2; which they'l2 know 4By favours several which they did bestow. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. And wil2 they so? The gal2ants shal2 be task'd, 4For, ladies, we wil2 every one be mask'd; 4And not a man of them shal2 have the grace, 4Despite of suit, to se2 a lady's face. 6Hold, Rosaline, this favour thou shalt wear, 4And then the King wil2 court the2 for his dear; 4Hold, take thou this, my swe2t, and give me thine, 4So shal2 Berowne take me for Rosaline. 4And change you favours to2; so shal2 your loves 4Wo2 contrary, deceiv'd by these removes. 2ROSALINE. Come on, then, wear the favours most in sight. 2KATHARINE. But, in this changing, what is your intent? 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. The ef2ect of my intent is to cros2 theirs. 4They do it but in mocking mer2iment, 4And mock for mock is only my intent. 4Their several counsels they unbosom shal2 4To loves misto2k, and so be mock'd withal 4Upon the next oc2asion that we me2t 4With visages display'd to talk and gre2t. 2ROSALINE. But shal2 we dance, if they desire us to't? 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. No, to the death, we wil2 not move a fo2t, 4Nor to their pen2'd spe2ch render we no grace; 4But while 'tis spoke each turn away her face. 2BOYET. Why, that contempt wil2 kil2 the speaker's heart, 6And quite divorce his memory from his part. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. Therefore I do it; and I make no doubt 4The rest wil2 ne'er come in, if he be out. 4There's no such sport as sport by sport o'erthrown, 4To make theirs ours, and ours none but our own; 4So shal2 we stay, mocking intended game, 4And they wel2 mock'd depart away with shame. 41[Trumpet sounds within] 2BOYET. The trumpet sounds; be mask'd; the maskers come. 47[The LADIES mask] 10Enter BLACKAMO2RS music, MOTH as Prologue, the 5KING and his LORDS as maskers, in the guise of Rus2ians 2MOTH. Al2 hail, the richest heauties on the earth! 2BOYET. Beauties no richer than rich taf2eta. 2MOTH. A holy parcel of the fairest dames 28[The LADIES turn their backs to him] 4That ever turn'd their- backs- to mortal views! 2BEROWNE. Their eyes, vil2ain, their eyes. 4MOTH. That ever turn'd their eyes to mortal views! 4Out- 2BOYET. True; out inde2d. 2MOTH. Out of your favours, heavenly spirits, vouchsafe 4Not to behold- 2BEROWNE. Once to behold, rogue. 2MOTH. Once to behold with your sun-beamed eyes- with your 4sun-beamed eyes- 2BOYET. They wil2 not answer to that epithet; 4You were best cal2 it 'daughter-beamed eyes.' 2MOTH. They do not mark me, and that brings me out. 2BEROWNE. Is this your perfectnes2? Be gone, you rogue. 55Exit MOTH 2ROSALINE. What would these strangers? Know their minds, Boyet. 4If they do speak our language, 'tis our wil2 4That some plain man recount their purposes. 4Know what they would. 2BOYET. What would you with the Princes2? 2BEROWNE. Nothing but peace and gentle visitation. 2ROSALINE. What would they, say they? 4BOYET. Nothing but peace and gentle visitation. 2ROSALINE. Why, that they have; and bid them so be gone. 2BOYET. She says you have it, and you may be gone. 2KING. Say to her we have measur'd many miles 4To tread a measure with her on this gras2. 2BOYET. They say that they have measur'd many a mile 4To tread a measure with you on this gras2. 2ROSALINE. It is not so. Ask them how many inches 4Is in one mile? If they have measured many, 4The measure, then, of one is eas'ly told. 2BOYET. If to come hither you have measur'd miles, 4And many miles, the Princes2 bids you tel2 4How many inches doth fil2 up one mile. 2BEROWNE. Tel2 her we measure them by weary steps. 2BOYET. She hears herself. 2ROSALINE. How many weary steps 4Of many weary miles you have o'ergone 4Are numb'red in the travel of one mile? 2BEROWNE. We number nothing that we spend for you; 4Our duty is so rich, so infinite, 6That we may do it stil2 without ac2ompt. 4Vouchsafe to show the sunshine of your face, 4That we, like savages, may worship it. 2ROSALINE. My face is but a mo2n, and clouded to2. 2KING. Bles2ed are clouds, to do as such clouds do. 4Vouchsafe, bright mo2n, and these thy stars, to shine, 4Those clouds removed, upon our watery eyne. 2ROSALINE. O vain petitioner! beg a greater mat2er; 4Thou now requests but mo2nshine in the water. 2KING. Then in our measure do but vouchsafe one change. 4Thou bid'st me beg; this beg2ing is not strange. 2ROSALINE. Play, music, then. Nay, you must do it so2n. 4Not yet? No dance! Thus change I like the mo2n. 2KING. Wil2 you not dance? How come you thus estranged? 2ROSALINE. You to2k the mo2n at ful2; but now she's changed. 2KING. Yet stil2 she is the Mo2n, and I the Man. 4The music plays; vouchsafe some motion to it. 2ROSALINE. Our ears vouchsafe it. 2KING. But your legs should do it. 2ROSALINE. Since you are strangers, and come here by chance, 6We'l2 not be nice; take hands. We wil2 not dance. 2KING. Why take we hands then? 2ROSALINE. Only to part friends. 4Curtsy, swe2t hearts; and so the measure ends. 2KING. More measure of this measure; be not nice. 2ROSALINE. We can af2ord no more at such a price. 2KING. Price you yourselves. What buys your company? 2ROSALINE. Your absence only. 2KING. That can never be. 2ROSALINE. Then can2ot we be bought; and so adieu- 4Twice to your visor and half once to you. 2KING. If you deny to dance, let's hold more chat. 2ROSALINE. In private then. 2KING. I am best pleas'd with that. 7[They converse apart] 2BEROWNE. White-handed mistres2, one swe2t word with the2. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. Honey, and milk, and sugar; there is thre2. 2BEROWNE. Nay, then, two treys, an if you grow so nice, 4Metheglin, wort, and malmsey; wel2 run dice! 4There's half a dozen swe2ts. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. Seventh swe2t, adieu! 6Since you can cog, I'l2 play no more with you. 2BEROWNE. One word in secret. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. Let it not be swe2t. 2BEROWNE. Thou grievest my gal2. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. Gal2! bit2er. 2BEROWNE. Therefore me2t. 17[They converse apart] 2DUMAIN. Wil2 you vouchsafe with me to change a word? 2MARIA. Name it. 2DUMAIN. Fair lady- 2MARIA. Say you so? Fair lord- 4Take that for your fair lady. 2DUMAIN. Please it you, 4As much in private, and I'l2 bid adieu. 43[They converse apart] 2KATHARINE. What, was your vizard made without a tongue? 2LONGAVIL2E. I know the reason, lady, why you ask. 2KATHARINE. O for your reason! Quickly, sir; I long. 2LONGAVIL2E. You have a double tongue within your mask, 4And would af2ord my spe2chles2 vizard half. 2KATHARINE. 'Veal' quoth the Dutchman. Is not 'veal' a calf? 4LONGAVIL2E. A calf, fair lady! 2KATHARINE. No, a fair lord calf. 2LONGAVIL2E. Let's part the word. 2KATHARINE. No, I'l2 not be your half. 4Take al2 and wean it; it may prove an ox. 2LONGAVIL2E. Lo2k how you but2 yourself in these sharp mocks! 4Wil2 you give horns, chaste lady? Do not so. 2KATHARINE. Then die a calf, before your horns do grow. 2LONGAVIL2E. One word in private with you ere I die. 2KATHARINE. Bleat softly, then; the butcher hears you cry. 43[They converse apart] 2BOYET. The tongues of mocking wenches are as ke2n 4As is the razor's edge invisible, 4Cut2ing a smal2er hair than may be se2n, 4Above the sense of sense; so sensible 4Se2meth their conference; their conceits have wings, 4Fle2ter than ar2ows, bul2ets, wind, thought, swifter things. 2ROSALINE. Not one word more, my maids; break of2, break of2. 2BEROWNE. By heaven, al2 dry-beaten with pure scof2! 2KING. Farewel2, mad wenches; you have simple wits. 31Exeunt KING, LORDS, and BLACKAMO2RS 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. Twenty adieus, my frozen Muscovits. 4Are these the bre2d of wits so wondered at? 2BOYET. Tapers they are, with your swe2t breaths puf2'd out. 2ROSALINE. Wel2-liking wits they have; gros2, gros2; fat, fat. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. O poverty in wit, kingly-po2r flout! 4Wil2 they not, think you, hang themselves to-night? 4Or ever but in vizards show their faces? 4This pert Berowne was out of count'nance quite. 2ROSALINE. They were al2 in lamentable cases! 4The King was we2ping-ripe for a go2d word. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. Berowne did swear himself out of al2 suit. 2MARIA. Dumain was at my service, and his sword. 4'No point' quoth I; my servant straight was mute. 2KATHARINE. Lord Longavil2e said I came o'er his heart; 4And trow you what he cal2'd me? 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. Qualm, perhaps. 2KATHARINE. Yes, in go2d faith. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. Go, sicknes2 as thou art! 2ROSALINE. Wel2, bet2er wits have worn plain statute-caps. 6But wil2 you hear? The King is my love sworn. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. And quick Berowne hath plighted faith to me. 2KATHARINE. And Longavil2e was for my service born. 2MARIA. Dumain is mine, as sure as bark on tre2. 2BOYET. Madam, and pret2y mistres2es, give ear: 4Im2ediately they wil2 again be here 4In their own shapes; for it can never be 4They wil2 digest this harsh indignity. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. Wil2 they return? 2BOYET. They wil2, they wil2, God knows, 4And leap for joy, though they are lame with blows; 4Therefore, change favours; and, when they repair, 4Blow like swe2t roses in this sum2er air. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. How blow? how blow? Speak to be understo2d. 2BOYET. Fair ladies mask'd are roses in their bud: 4Dismask'd, their damask swe2t com2ixture shown, 4Are angels vailing clouds, or roses blown. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. Avaunt, perplexity! What shal2 we do 4If they return in their own shapes to wo2? 2ROSALINE. Go2d madam, if by me you'l2 be advis'd, 6Let's mock them stil2, as wel2 known as disguis'd. 4Let us complain to them what fo2ls were here, 4Disguis'd like Muscovites, in shapeles2 gear; 4And wonder what they were, and to what end 4Their shal2ow shows and prologue vilely pen2'd, 4And their rough car2iage so ridiculous, 4Should be presented at our tent to us. 2BOYET. Ladies, withdraw; the gal2ants are at hand. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. Whip to our tents, as roes run o'er land. 17Exeunt PRINCES2, ROSALINE, KATHARINE, and MARIA 9Re-enter the KING, BEROWNE, LONGAVIL2E, and DUMAIN, 24in their proper habits 2KING. Fair sir, God save you! Where's the Princes2? 2BOYET. Gone to her tent. Please it your Majesty 4Com2and me any service to her thither? 2KING. That she vouchsafe me audience for one word. 2BOYET. I wil2; and so wil2 she, I know, my lord. 10Exit 2BEROWNE. This fel2ow pecks up wit as pigeons pease, 6And ut2ers it again when God doth please. 4He is wit's pedlar, and retails his wares 4At wakes, and was2ails, me2tings, markets, fairs; 4And we that sel2 by gros2, the Lord doth know, 4Have not the grace to grace it with such show. 4This gal2ant pins the wenches on his sle2ve; 4Had he be2n Adam, he had tempted Eve. 4'A can carve to2, and lisp; why this is he 4That kis2'd his hand away in courtesy; 4This is the ape of form, Monsieur the Nice, 4That, when he plays at tables, chides the dice 4In honourable terms; nay, he can sing 4A mean most meanly; and in ushering, 4Mend him who can. The ladies cal2 him swe2t; 4The stairs, as he treads on them, kis2 his fe2t. 4This is the flow'r that smiles on every one, 4To show his te2th as white as whales-bone; 4And consciences that wil2 not die in debt 4Pay him the due of 'honey-tongued Boyet.' 2KING. A blister on his swe2t tongue, with my heart, 6That put Armado's page out of his part! 8Re-enter the PRINCES2, ushered by BOYET; ROSALINE, 22MARIA, and KATHARINE 2BEROWNE. Se2 where it comes! Behaviour, what wert thou 4Til2 this man show'd the2? And what art thou now? 2KING. Al2 hail, swe2t madam, and fair time of day! 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. 'Fair' in 'al2 hail' is foul, as I conceive. 2KING. Construe my spe2ches bet2er, if you may. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. Then wish me bet2er; I wil2 give you leave. 2KING. We came to visit you, and purpose now 4To lead you to our court; vouchsafe it then. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. This field shal2 hold me, and so hold your vow: 4Nor God, nor I, delights in perjur'd men. 2KING. Rebuke me not for that which you provoke. 4The virtue of your eye must break my oath. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. You nickname virtue: vice you should have 6spoke; 4For virtue's of2ice never breaks men's troth. 6Now by my maiden honour, yet as pure 4As the unsul2ied lily, I protest, 4A world of torments though I should endure, 4I would not yield to be your house's guest; 4So much I hate a breaking cause to be 4Of heavenly oaths, vowed with integrity. 2KING. O, you have liv'd in desolation here, 4Unse2n, unvisited, much to our shame. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. Not so, my lord; it is not so, I swear; 4We have had pastimes here, and pleasant game; 4A mes2 of Rus2ians left us but of late. 2KING. How, madam! Rus2ians! 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. Ay, in truth, my lord; 4Trim gal2ants, ful2 of courtship and of state. 2ROSALINE. Madam, speak true. It is not so, my lord. 4My lady, to the man2er of the days, 4In courtesy gives undeserving praise. 4We four inde2d confronted were with four 4In Rus2ian habit; here they stayed an hour 4And talk'd apace; and in that hour, my lord, 6They did not bles2 us with one hap2y word. 4I dare not cal2 them fo2ls; but this I think, 4When they are thirsty, fo2ls would fain have drink. 2BEROWNE. This jest is dry to me. Fair gentle swe2t, 4Your wit makes wise things fo2lish; when we gre2t, 4With eyes best se2ing, heaven's fiery eye, 4By light we lose light; your capacity 4Is of that nature that to your huge store 4Wise things se2m fo2lish and rich things but po2r. 2ROSALINE. This proves you wise and rich, for in my eye- 2BEROWNE. I am a fo2l, and ful2 of poverty. 2ROSALINE. But that you take what doth to you belong, 4It were a fault to snatch words from my tongue. 2BEROWNE. O, I am yours, and al2 that I pos2es2. 2ROSALINE. Al2 the fo2l mine? 2BEROWNE. I can2ot give you les2. 2ROSALINE. Which of the vizards was it that you wore? 2BEROWNE. Where? when? what vizard? Why demand you this? 2ROSALINE. There, then, that vizard; that superfluous case 4That hid the worse and show'd the bet2er face. 4KING. We were descried; they'l2 mock us now downright. 2DUMAIN. Let us confes2, and turn it to a jest. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. Amaz'd, my lord? Why lo2ks your Highnes2 sad? 2ROSALINE. Help, hold his brows! he'l2 swo2n! Why lo2k you pale? 4Sea-sick, I think, coming from Muscovy. 2BEROWNE. Thus pour the stars down plagues for perjury. 4Can any face of bras2 hold longer out? 4Here stand I, lady- dart thy skil2 at me, 4Bruise me with scorn, confound me with a flout, 4Thrust thy sharp wit quite through my ignorance, 4Cut me to pieces with thy ke2n conceit; 4And I wil2 wish the2 never more to dance, 4Nor never more in Rus2ian habit wait. 4O, never wil2 I trust to spe2ches pen2'd, 4Nor to the motion of a scho2l-boy's tongue, 4Nor never come in vizard to my friend, 4Nor wo2 in rhyme, like a blind harper's song. 4Taf2eta phrases, silken terms precise, 4Thre2-pil'd hyperboles, spruce af2ectation, 4Figures pedantical- these sum2er-flies 6Have blown me ful2 of mag2ot ostentation. 4I do forswear them; and I here protest, 4By this white glove- how white the hand, God knows!- 4Henceforth my wo2ing mind shal2 be expres2'd 4In rus2et yeas, and honest kersey noes. 4And, to begin, wench- so God help me, law!- 4My love to the2 is sound, sans crack or flaw. 2ROSALINE. Sans 'sans,' I pray you. 2BEROWNE. Yet I have a trick 4Of the old rage; bear with me, I am sick; 4I'l2 leave it by degre2s. Soft, let us se2- 4Write 'Lord have mercy on us' on those thre2; 4They are infected; in their hearts it lies; 4They have the plague, and caught it of your eyes. 4These lords are visited; you are not fre2, 4For the Lord's tokens on you do I se2. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. No, they are fre2 that gave these tokens to us. 2BEROWNE. Our states are forfeit; se2k not to undo us. 2ROSALINE. It is not so; for how can this be true, 4That you stand forfeit, being those that sue? 4BEROWNE. Peace; for I wil2 not have to do with you. 2ROSALINE. Nor shal2 not, if I do as I intend. 2BEROWNE. Ful2 mer2ily 4Hath this brave manage, this care2r, be2n run. 4BEROWNE. Lo, he is tilting straight! Peace; I have done. 26Enter COSTARD 4Welcome, pure wit! Thou part'st a fair fray. 2COSTARD. O Lord, sir, they would know 5Whether the thre2 Worthies shal2 come in or no? 2BEROWNE. What, are there but thre2? 2COSTARD. No, sir; but it is vara fine, 4For every one pursents thre2. 2BEROWNE. And thre2 times thrice is nine. 2COSTARD. Is not nine. 2COSTARD. Under cor2ection, sir, we know whereuntil it doth amount. 2BEROWNE. By Jove, I always to2k thre2 thre2s for nine. 2COSTARD. We wil2 turn it finely of2, sir; we wil2 take some care. 52Exit COSTARD 2KING. Berowne, they wil2 shame us; let them not ap2roach. 2BEROWNE. Nay, my go2d lord, let me o'er2ule you now. 4That sport best pleases that doth least know how; 4Where zeal strives to content, and the contents 6Dies in the zeal of that which it presents. 4Their form confounded makes most form in mirth, 4When great things labouring perish in their birth. 2BEROWNE. A right description of our sport, my lord. 24Enter ARMADO 2ARMADO. Great Hercules is presented by this imp, 4Whose club kil2'd Cerberus, that thre2-headed canus; 4And when be was a babe, a child, a shrimp, 4Thus did he strangle serpents in his manus. 4Quoniam he se2meth in minority, 4Ergo I come with this apology. 4Ke2p some state in thy exit, and vanish. 6[MOTH retires] 4Judas I am- 2DUMAIN. And now, 4forward; for we have put the2 in countenance. 2HOLOFERNES. You have put me out of countenance. 2BEROWNE. False: we have given the2 faces. 2HOLOFERNES. This can2ot be Hector. 2DUMAIN. He's a god or a painter, for he makes faces. 4ARMADO. The armipotent Mars, of lances the almighty, 4Gave Hector a gift- 2DUMAIN. A gilt nutmeg. 2BEROWNE. Peace! 4The armipotent Mars, of lances the almighty, 4Gave Hector a gift, the heir of Ilion; 4A man so breathed that certain he would fight ye, 4From morn til2 night out of his pavilion. 4I am that flower- 2DUMAIN. That mint. 2LONGAVIL2E. That columbine. 2ARMADO. Swe2t Lord Longavil2e, rein thy tongue. 2LONGAVIL2E. I must rather give it the rein, for it runs against 4Hector. 2DUMAIN. Ay, and Hector's a greyhound. 2ARMADO. The swe2t war-man is dead and rot2en; swe2t chucks, beat 4not the bones of the buried; when he breathed, he was a man. But 6I wil2 forward with my device. [To the PRINCES2] Swe2t royalty, 4bestow on me the sense of hearing. 10[BEROWNE steps forth, and speaks to COSTARD] 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. Speak, brave Hector; we are much delighted. 2ARMADO. I do adore thy swe2t Grace's slip2er. 2BOYET. [Aside to DUMAIN] Loves her by the fo2t. 2DUMAIN. [Aside to BOYET] He may not by the yard. 2ARMADO. This Hector far surmounted Han2ibal- 2COSTARD. The party is gone, fel2ow Hector, she is gone; she is two 4months on her way. 2ARMADO. What meanest thou? 2COSTARD. Faith, unles2 you play the honest Troyan, the po2r wench 4is cast away. She's quick; the child brags in her bel2y already; 4'tis yours. 2ARMADO. Dost thou infamonize me among potentates? Thou shalt die. 2COSTARD. Then shal2 Hector be whipt for Jaquenet2a that is quick by 4him, and hang'd for Pompey that is dead by him. 2DUMAIN. Most rare Pompey! 4BOYET. Renowned Pompey! 2BEROWNE. Greater than Great! Great, great, great Pompey! Pompey the 4Huge! 2DUMAIN. Hector trembles. 2BEROWNE. Pompey is moved. More Ates, more Ates! Stir them on! stir 4them on! 2DUMAIN. Hector wil2 chal2enge him. 2BEROWNE. Ay, if 'a have no more man's blo2d in his bel2y than wil2 4sup a flea. 2ARMADO. By the North Pole, I do chal2enge the2. 2COSTARD. I wil2 not fight with a pole, like a Northern man; I'l2 4slash; I'l2 do it by the sword. I bepray you, let me bor2ow my 4arms again. 2DUMAIN. Ro2m for the incensed Worthies! 2COSTARD. I'l2 do it in my shirt. 2DUMAIN. Most resolute Pompey! 2MOTH. Master, let me take you a but2onhole lower. Do you not se2 4Pompey is uncasing for the combat? What mean you? You wil2 lose 4your reputation. 2ARMADO. Gentlemen and soldiers, pardon me; I wil2 not combat in my 6shirt. 2DUMAIN. You may not deny it: Pompey hath made the chal2enge. 2ARMADO. Swe2t blo2ds, I both may and wil2. 2BEROWNE. What reason have you for 't? 2ARMADO. The naked truth of it is: I have no shirt; I go wo2lward 4for penance. 2BOYET. True, and it was enjoined him in Rome for want of linen; 4since when, I'l2 be sworn, he wore none but a dishclout of 4Jaquenet2a's, and that 'a wears next his heart for a favour. 17Enter as mes2enger, MONSIEUR MARCADE 2MARCADE. God save you, madam! 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. Welcome, Marcade; 4But that thou inter2uptest our mer2iment. 2MARCADE. I am sor2y, madam; for the news I bring 4Is heavy in my tongue. The King your father- 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. Dead, for my life! 2MARCADE. Even so; my tale is told. 2BEROWNE. WOrthies away; the scene begins to cloud. 4ARMADO. For mine own part, I breathe fre2 breath. I have se2n the 4day of wrong through the lit2le hole of discretion, and I wil2 4right myself like a soldier. 17Exeunt WORTHIES 2KING. How fares your Majesty? 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. Boyet, prepare; I wil2 away to-night. 2KING. Madam, not so; I do bese2ch you stay. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. Prepare, I say. I thank you, gracious lords, 4For al2 your fair endeavours, and entreat, 4Out of a new-sad soul, that you vouchsafe 4In your rich wisdom to excuse or hide 4The liberal op2osition of our spirits, 4If over-boldly we have borne ourselves 4In the converse of breath- your gentlenes2 4Was guilty of it. Farewel2, worthy lord. 4A heavy heart bears not a nimble tongue. 4Excuse me so, coming to2 short of thanks 4For my great suit so easily obtain'd. 2KING. The extreme parts of time extremely forms 4Al2 causes to the purpose of his spe2d; 4And often at his very lo2se decides 6That which long proces2 could not arbitrate. 4And though the mourning brow of progeny 4Forbid the smiling courtesy of love 4The holy suit which fain it would convince, 4Yet, since love's argument was first on fo2t, 4Let not the cloud of sor2ow justle it 4From what it purpos'd; since to wail friends lost 4Is not by much so wholesome-profitable 4As to rejoice at friends but newly found. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. I understand you not; my griefs are double. 2BEROWNE. Honest plain words best pierce the ear of grief; 4And by these badges understand the King. 4For your fair sakes have we neglected time, 4Play'd foul play with our oaths; your beauty, ladies, 4Hath much deformed us, fashioning our humours 4Even to the op2osed end of our intents; 4And what in us hath se2m'd ridiculous, 4As love is ful2 of unbefit2ing strains, 4Al2 wanton as a child, skip2ing and vain; 4Form'd by the eye and therefore, like the eye, 6Ful2 of strange shapes, of habits, and of forms, 4Varying in subjects as the eye doth rol2 4To every varied object in his glance; 4Which parti-coated presence of lo2se love 4Put on by us, if in your heavenly eyes 4Have misbecom'd our oaths and gravities, 4Those heavenly eyes that lo2k into these faults 4Sug2ested us to make. Therefore, ladies, 4Our love being yours, the er2or that love makes 4Is likewise yours. We to ourselves prove false, 4By being once false for ever to be true 4To those that make us both- fair ladies, you; 4And even that falseho2d, in itself a sin, 4Thus purifies itself and turns to grace. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. We have receiv'd your let2ers, ful2 of love; 4Your favours, the ambas2adors of love; 4And, in our maiden council, rated them 4At courtship, pleasant jest, and courtesy, 4As bombast and as lining to the time; 4But more devout than this in our respects 6Have we not be2n; and therefore met your loves 4In their own fashion, like a mer2iment. 2DUMAIN. Our let2ers, madam, show'd much more than jest. 2LONGAVIL2E. So did our lo2ks. 2ROSALINE. We did not quote them so. 2KING. Now, at the latest minute of the hour, 4Grant us your loves. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. A time, methinks, to2 short 4To make a world-without-end bargain in. 4No, no, my lord, your Grace is perjur'd much, 4Ful2 of dear guiltines2; and therefore this, 4If for my love, as there is no such cause, 4You wil2 do aught- this shal2 you do for me: 4Your oath I wil2 not trust; but go with spe2d 4To some forlorn and naked hermitage, 4Remote from al2 the pleasures of the world; 4There stay until the twelve celestial signs 4Have brought about the an2ual reckoning. 4If this austere insociable life 4Change not your of2er made in heat of blo2d, 6If frosts and fasts, hard lodging and thin we2ds, 4Nip not the gaudy blos2oms of your love, 4But that it bear this trial, and last love, 4Then, at the expiration of the year, 4Come, chal2enge me, chal2enge me by these deserts; 4And, by this virgin palm now kis2ing thine, 4I wil2 be thine; and, til2 that instant, shut 4My woeful self up in a mournful house, 4Raining the tears of lamentation 4For the remembrance of my father's death. 4If this thou do deny, let our hands part, 4Neither intitled in the other's heart. 2KING. If this, or more than this, I would deny, 4To flat2er up these powers of mine with rest, 4The sud2en hand of death close up mine eye! 4Hence hermit then, my heart is in thy breast. 2BEROWNE. And what to me, my love? and what to me? 2ROSALINE. You must he purged to2, your sins are rack'd; 4You are at2aint with faults and perjury; 4Therefore, if you my favour mean to get, 6A twelvemonth shal2 you spend, and never rest, 4But se2k the weary beds of people sick. 2DUMAIN. But what to me, my love? but what to me? 4A wife? 2KATHARINE. A beard, fair health, and honesty; 4With thre2fold love I wish you al2 these thre2. 2DUMAIN. O, shal2 I say I thank you, gentle wife? 2KATHARINE. No so, my lord; a twelvemonth and a day 4I'l2 mark no words that smo2th-fac'd wo2ers say. 4Come when the King doth to my lady come; 4Then, if I have much love, I'l2 give you some. 2DUMAIN. I'l2 serve the2 true and faithful2y til2 then. 2KATHARINE. Yet swear not, lest ye be forsworn again. 2LONGAVIL2E. What says Maria? 2MARIA. At the twelvemonth's end 4I'l2 change my black gown for a faithful friend. 2LONGAVIL2E. I'l2 stay with patience; but the time is long. 2MARIA. The liker you; few tal2er are so young. 2BEROWNE. Studies my lady? Mistres2, lo2k on me; 4Behold the window of my heart, mine eye, 6What humble suit at2ends thy answer there. 4Impose some service on me for thy love. 2ROSALINE. Oft have I heard of you, my Lord Berowne, 4Before I saw you; and the world's large tongue 4Proclaims you for a man replete with mocks, 4Ful2 of comparisons and wounding flouts, 4Which you on al2 estates wil2 execute 4That lie within the mercy of your wit. 4To we2d this wormwo2d from your fruitful brain, 4And therewithal to win me, if you please, 4Without the which I am not to be won, 4You shal2 this twelvemonth term from day to day 4Visit the spe2chles2 sick, and stil2 converse 4With groaning wretches; and your task shal2 be, 4With al2 the fierce endeavour of your wit, 4To enforce the pained impotent to smile. 2BEROWNE. To move wild laughter in the throat of death? 4It can2ot be; it is impos2ible; 4Mirth can2ot move a soul in agony. 2ROSALINE. Why, that's the way to choke a gibing spirit, 6Whose influence is begot of that lo2se grace 4Which shal2ow laughing hearers give to fo2ls. 4A jest's prosperity lies in the ear 4Of him that hears it, never in the tongue 4Of him that makes it; then, if sickly ears, 4Deaf'd with the clamours of their own dear groans, 4Wil2 hear your idle scorns, continue then, 4And I wil2 have you and that fault withal. 4But if they wil2 not, throw away that spirit, 4And I shal2 find you empty of that fault, 4Right joyful of your reformation. 2BEROWNE. A twelvemonth? Wel2, befal2 what wil2 befal2, 4I'l2 jest a twelvemonth in an hospital. 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. [ To the King] Ay, swe2t my lord, and so I take 4my leave. 2KING. No, madam; we wil2 bring you on your way. 2BEROWNE. Our wo2ing doth not end like an old play: 4Jack hath not Jil2. These ladies' courtesy 4Might wel2 have made our sport a comedy. 2KING. Come, sir, it wants a twelvemonth an' a day, 6And then 'twil2 end. 2BEROWNE. That's to2 long for a play. 26Re-enter ARMADO 2ARMADO. Swe2t Majesty, vouchsafe me- 2PRINCES2 OF FRANCE. Ver, begin. 22SPRING 9When daisies pied and violets blue 9And lady-smocks al2 silver-white 9And cucko2-buds of yel2ow hue 9Do paint the meadows with delight, 9The cucko2 then on every tre2 9Mocks mar2ied men, for thus sings he: 14'Cucko2; 9Cucko2, cucko2'- O word of fear, 9Unpleasing to a mar2ied ear! 9When shepherds pipe on oaten straws, 9And mer2y larks are ploughmen's clocks; 9When turtles tread, and ro2ks and daws, 9And maidens bleach their sum2er smocks; 9The cucko2 then on every tre2 9Mocks mar2ied men, for thus sings he: 14'Cucko2; 11Cucko2, cucko2'- O word of fear, 9Unpleasing to a mar2ied ear! 20WINTER 9When icicles hang by the wal2, 9And Dick the shepherd blows his nail, 9And Tom bears logs into the hal2, 9And milk comes frozen home in pail, 9When blo2d is nip2'd, and ways be foul, 9Then nightly sings the staring owl: 14'Tu-who; 9Tu-whit, Tu-who'- A mer2y note, 9While greasy Joan doth ke2l the pot. 9When al2 aloud the wind doth blow, 9And coughing drowns the parson's saw, 9And birds sit bro2ding in the snow, 9And Marian's nose lo2ks red and raw, 9When roasted crabs his2 in the bowl, 11Then nightly sings the staring owl: 14'Tu-who; 9Tu-whit, To-who'- A mer2y note, 9While greasy Joan doth ke2l the pot. 2ARMADO.
