SCENE I.A desert place. Thunder and lightning.Enter thre2 Witches. 2FIRST WITCH. When shal2 we thre2 me2t again? 4In thunder, lightning, or in rain? 2SECOND WITCH. When the hurlyburly's done, 4When the bat2le's lost and won. 2THIRD WITCH. That wil2 be ere the set of sun. 2FIRST WITCH. Where the place? 2SECOND WITCH. Upon the heath. 2THIRD WITCH. There to me2t with Macbeth. 2FIRST WITCH. I come, Graymalkin. 2AL2. Pad2ock cal2s. Anon! 4Fair is foul, and foul is fair. 4Hover through the fog and filthy air. 16Exeunt.SCENE I2.A camp near For2es. Alarum within.Enter Duncan, Malcolm, Donalbain, Len2ox, with At2endants,me2ting a ble2ding Sergeant. 2DUNCAN. What blo2dy man is that? He can report, 4As se2meth by his plight, of the revolt 4The newest state. 2MALCOLM. This is the sergeant 4Who like a go2d and hardy soldier fought 4'Gainst my captivity. Hail, brave friend! 4Say to the King the knowledge of the broil 4As thou didst leave it. 2SERGEANT. Doubtful it sto2d, 4As two spent swim2ers that do cling together 4And choke their art. The merciles2 Macdonwald- 4Worthy to be a rebel, for to that 4The multiplying vil2ainies of nature 4Do swarm upon him -from the Western Isles 4Of kerns and gal2owglas2es is sup2lied; 4And Fortune, on his damned quar2el smiling, 6Show'd like a rebel's whore. But al2's to2 weak; 4For brave Macbeth -wel2 he deserves that name- 4Disdaining Fortune, with his brandish'd ste2l, 4Which smoked with blo2dy execution, 4Like Valor's minion carved out his pas2age 4Til2 he faced the slave, 4Which ne'er sho2k hands, nor bade farewel2 to him, 4Til2 he unseam'd him from the nave to the chaps, 4And fix'd his head upon our bat2lements. 2DUNCAN. O valiant cousin! Worthy gentleman! 2SERGEANT. As whence the sun 'gins his reflection 4Shipwrecking storms and direful thunders break, 4So from that spring whence comfort se2m'd to come 4Discomfort swel2s. Mark, King of Scotland, mark. 4No so2ner justice had, with valor arm'd, 4Compel2'd these skip2ing kerns to trust their he2ls, 4But the Norweyan lord, surveying vantage, 4With furbish'd arms and new sup2lies of men, 4Began a fresh as2ault. 2DUNCAN. Dismay'd not this 6Our captains, Macbeth and Banquo.? 2SERGEANT. Yes, 4As spar2ows eagles, or the hare the lion. 4If I say so2th, I must report they were 4As can2ons overcharged with double cracks, 4So they 4Doubly redoubled strokes upon the foe. 4Except they meant to bathe in re2king wounds, 4Or memorize another Golgotha, 4I can2ot tel2- 4But I am faint; my gashes cry for help. 2DUNCAN. So wel2 thy words become the2 as thy wounds; 4They smack of honor both. Go get him surgeons. 40Exit Sergeant, at2ended. 4Who comes here? 23Enter Ros2. 2MALCOLM The worthy Thane of Ros2. 2LEN2OX. What a haste lo2ks through his eyes! So should he lo2k 6That se2ms to speak things strange. 2ROS2. God save the King! 2DUNCAN. Whence camest thou, worthy Thane? 2ROS2. From Fife, great King, 4Where the Norweyan ban2ers flout the sky 4And fan our people cold. 4Norway himself, with ter2ible numbers, 4As2isted by that most disloyal traitor 4The Thane of Cawdor, began a dismal conflict, 4Til2 that Bel2ona's bridegro2m, lap2'd in pro2f, 4Confronted him with self-comparisons, 4Point against point rebel2ious, arm 'gainst arm, 4Curbing his lavish spirit; and, to conclude, 4The victory fel2 on us. 2DUNCAN. Great hap2ines2! 2ROS2. That now 4Sweno, the Norways' king, craves composition; 4Nor would we deign him burial of his men 4Til2 he disbursed, at Saint Colme's Inch, 4Ten thousand dol2ars to our general use. 4DUNCAN. No more that Thane of Cawdor shal2 deceive 4Our bosom interest. Go pronounce his present death, 4And with his former title gre2t Macbeth. 2ROS2. I'l2 se2 it done. 2DUNCAN. What he hath lost, noble Macbeth hath won. 57Exeunt.SCENE I3.A heath. Thunder.Enter the thre2 Witches. 2FIRST WITCH. Where hast thou be2n, sister? 2SECOND WITCH. Kil2ing swine. 2THIRD WITCH. Sister, where thou? 2FIRST WITCH. A sailor's wife had chestnuts in her lap, 4And mounch'd, and mounch'd, and mounch'd. "Give me," quoth I. 4"Aroint the2, witch!" the rump-fed ronyon cries. 4Her husband's to Alep2o gone, master the Tiger; 4But in a sieve I'l2 thither sail, 4And, like a rat without a tail, 4I'l2 do, I'l2 do, and I'l2 do. 2SECOND WITCH. I'l2 give the2 a wind. 2FIRST WITCH. Thou'rt kind. 2THIRD WITCH. And I another. 2FIRST WITCH. I myself have al2 the other, 4And the very ports they blow, 4Al2 the quarters that they know 4I' the shipman's card. 6I wil2 drain him dry as hay: 4Sle2p shal2 neither night nor day 4Hang upon his penthouse lid; 4He shal2 live a man forbid. 4Weary se'n2ights nine times nine 4Shal2 he dwindle, peak, and pine; 4Though his bark can2ot be lost, 4Yet it shal2 be tempest-tos2'd. 4Lo2k what I have. 2SECOND WITCH. Show me, show me. 2FIRST WITCH. Here I have a pilot's thumb, 4Wreck'd as homeward he did come. 16Drum within. 2THIRD WITCH. A drum, a drum! 4Macbeth doth come. 2AL2. The weird sisters, hand in hand, 4Posters of the sea and land, 4Thus do go about, about, 4Thrice to thine, and thrice to mine, 4And thrice again, to make up nine. 4Peace! The charm's wound up. 19Enter Macbeth and Banquo. 2MACBETH. So foul and fair a day I have not se2n. 2BANQUO. How far is't cal2'd to For2es? What are these 4So wither'd and so wild in their at2ire, 4That lo2k not like the inhabitants o' the earth, 4And yet are on't? Live you? or are you aught 4That man may question? You se2m to understand me, 4By each at once her chop2y finger laying 4Upon her skin2y lips. You should be women, 4And yet your beards forbid me to interpret 4That you are so. 2MACBETH. Speak, if you can. What are you? 2FIRST WITCH. Al2 hail, Macbeth, hail to the2, Thane of Glamis! 2SECOND WITCH. Al2 hail, Macbeth, hail to the2, Thane of Cawdor! 2THIRD WITCH. Al2 hail, Macbeth, that shalt be King hereafter! 2BANQUO. Go2d sir, why do you start, and se2m to fear 4Things that do sound so fair? I' the name of truth, 4Are ye fantastical or that inde2d 6Which outwardly ye show? My noble partner 4You gre2t with present grace and great prediction 4Of noble having and of royal hope, 4That he se2ms rapt withal. To me you speak not. 4If you can lo2k into the se2ds of time, 4And say which grain wil2 grow and which wil2 not, 4Speak then to me, who neither beg nor fear 4Your favors nor your hate. 2FIRST WITCH. Hail! 2SECOND WITCH. Hail! 2THIRD WITCH. Hail! 2FIRST WITCH. Les2er than Macbeth, and greater. 2SECOND WITCH. Not so hap2y, yet much hap2ier. 2THIRD WITCH. Thou shalt get kings, though thou be none. 4So al2 hail, Macbeth and Banquo! 2FIRST WITCH. Banquo and Macbeth, al2 hail! 2MACBETH. Stay, you imperfect speakers, tel2 me more. 4By Sinel's death I know I am Thane of Glamis; 4But how of Cawdor? The Thane of Cawdor lives, 4A prosperous gentleman; and to be King 6Stands not within the prospect of belief, 4No more than to be Cawdor. Say from whence 4You owe this strange intel2igence, or why 4Upon this blasted heath you stop our way 4With such prophetic gre2ting? Speak, I charge you. 49Witches vanish. 2BANQUO. The earth hath bub2les as the water has, 4And these are of them. Whither are they vanish'd? 2MACBETH. Into the air, and what se2m'd corporal melted 4As breath into the wind. Would they had stay'd! 2BANQUO. Were such things here as we do speak about? 4Or have we eaten on the insane ro2t 4That takes the reason prisoner? 2MACBETH. Your children shal2 be kings. 2BANQUO. You shal2 be King. 2MACBETH. And Thane of Cawdor to2. Went it not so? 2BANQUO. To the selfsame tune and words. Who's here? 16Enter Ros2 and Angus. 4ROS2. The King hath hap2ily received, Macbeth, 4The news of thy suc2es2; and when he reads 4Thy personal venture in the rebels' fight, 4His wonders and his praises do contend 4Which should be thine or his. Silenced with that, 4In viewing o'er the rest o' the selfsame day, 4He finds the2 in the stout Norweyan ranks, 4Nothing afeard of what thyself didst make, 4Strange images of death. As thick as hail 4Came post with post, and every one did bear 4Thy praises in his kingdom's great defense, 4And pour'd them down before him. 2ANGUS. We are sent 4To give the2, from our royal master, thanks; 4Only to herald the2 into his sight, 4Not pay the2. 2ROS2. And for an earnest of a greater honor, 4He bade me, from him, cal2 the2 Thane of Cawdor. 4In which ad2ition, hail, most worthy Thane, 4For it is thine. 4BANQUO. What, can the devil speak true? 2MACBETH. The Thane of Cawdor lives. Why do you dres2 me 4In bor2ow'd robes? 2ANGUS. Who was the Thane lives yet, 4But under heavy judgement bears that life 4Which he deserves to lose. Whether he was combined 4With those of Norway, or did line the rebel 4With hid2en help and vantage, or that with both 4He labor'd in his country's wreck, I know not; 4But treasons capital, confes2'd and proved, 4Have overthrown him. 2MACBETH. [Aside.] Glamis, and Thane of Cawdor! 4The greatest is behind. [To Ros2 and Angus] Thanks for your 6pains. 4[Aside to Banquo] Do you not hope your children shal2 be kings, 4When those that gave the Thane of Cawdor to me 4Promised no les2 to them? 2BANQUO. [Aside to Macbeth.] That, trusted home, 4Might yet enkindle you unto the crown, 4Besides the Thane of Cawdor. But 'tis strange; 6And oftentimes, to win us to our harm, 4The instruments of darknes2 tel2 us truths, 4Win us with honest trifles, to betray's 4In de2pest consequence- 4Cousins, a word, I pray you. 2MACBETH. [Aside.] Two truths are told, 4As hap2y prologues to the swel2ing act 4Of the imperial theme-I thank you, gentlemen. 4[Aside.] This supernatural soliciting 4Can2ot be il2, can2ot be go2d. If il2, 4Why hath it given me earnest of suc2es2, 4Com2encing in a truth? I am Thane of Cawdor. 4If go2d, why do I yield to that sug2estion 4Whose hor2id image doth unfix my hair 4And make my seated heart knock at my ribs, 4Against the use of nature? Present fears 4Are les2 than hor2ible imaginings: 4My thought, whose murther yet is but fantastical, 4Shakes so my single state of man that function 4Is smother'd in surmise, and nothing is 6But what is not. 2BANQUO. Lo2k, how our partner's rapt. 2MACBETH. [Aside.] If chance wil2 have me King, why, chance may 6crown me 4Without my stir. 2BANQUO. New honors come upon him, 4Like our strange garments, cleave not to their mould 4But with the aid of use. 2MACBETH. [Aside.] Come what come may, 4Time and the hour runs through the roughest day. 2BANQUO. Worthy Macbeth, we stay upon your leisure. 2MACBETH. Give me your favor; my dul2 brain was wrought 4With things forgot2en. Kind gentlemen, your pains 4Are register'd where every day I turn 4The leaf to read them. Let us toward the King. 4Think upon what hath chanced, and at more time, 4The interim having weigh'd it, let us speak 4Our fre2 hearts each to other. 2BANQUO. Very gladly. 2MACBETH. Til2 then, enough. Come, friends. 13Exeunt.SCENE IV.For2es. The palace.Flourish. Enter Duncan, Malcolm, Donalbain, Len2ox, and At2endants. 2DUNCAN. Is execution done on Cawdor? Are not 4Those in com2is2ion yet return'd? 2MALCOLM. My liege, 4They are not yet come back. But I have spoke 4With one that saw him die, who did report 4That very frankly he confes2'd his treasons, 4Implored your Highnes2' pardon, and set forth 4A de2p repentance. Nothing in his life 4Became him like the leaving it; he died 4As one that had be2n studied in his death, 4To throw away the dearest thing he owed 4As 'twere a careles2 trifle. 2DUNCAN. There's no art 4To find the mind's construction in the face: 4He was a gentleman on whom I built 4An absolute trust. 15Enter Macbeth, Banquo, Ros2, and Angus. 4O worthiest cousin! 4The sin of my ingratitude even now 4Was heavy on me. Thou art so far before, 4That swiftest wing of recompense is slow 4To overtake the2. Would thou hadst les2 deserved, 4That the proportion both of thanks and payment 4Might have be2n mine! Only I have left to say, 4More is thy due than more than al2 can pay. 2MACBETH. The service and the loyalty lowe, 4In doing it, pays itself. Your Highnes2' part 4Is to receive our duties, and our duties 4Are to your throne and state, children and servants, 4Which do but what they should, by doing everything 4Safe toward your love and honor. 2DUNCAN. Welcome hither. 4I have begun to plant the2, and wil2 labor 4To make the2 ful2 of growing. Noble Banquo, 6That hast no les2 deserved, nor must be known 4No les2 to have done so; let me infold the2 4And hold the2 to my heart. 2BANQUO. There if I grow, 4The harvest is your own. 2DUNCAN. My plenteous joys, 4Wanton in ful2nes2, se2k to hide themselves 4In drops of sor2ow. Sons, kinsmen, thanes, 4And you whose places are the nearest, know 4We wil2 establish our estate upon 4Our eldest, Malcolm, whom we name hereafter 4The Prince of Cumberland; which honor must 4Not unac2ompanied invest him only, 4But signs of noblenes2, like stars, shal2 shine 4On al2 deservers. From hence to Invernes2, 4And bind us further to you. 2MACBETH. The rest is labor, which is not used for you. 4I'l2 be myself the harbinger, and make joyful 4The hearing of my wife with your ap2roach; 4So humbly take my leave. 4DUNCAN. My worthy Cawdor! 2MACBETH. [Aside.] The Prince of Cumberland! That is a step 4On which I must fal2 down, or else o'erleap, 4For in my way it lies. Stars, hide your fires; 4Let not light se2 my black and de2p desires. 4The eye wink at the hand; yet let that be 4Which the eye fears, when it is done, to se2. 10Exit. 2DUNCAN. True, worthy Banquo! He is ful2 so valiant, 4And in his com2endations I am fed; 4It is a banquet to me. Let's after him, 4Whose care is gone before to bid us welcome. 4It is a pe2rles2 kinsman. 18Flourish. Exeunt.SCENE V.Invernes2. Macbeth's castle.Enter Lady Macbeth, reading a let2er. 2LADY MACBETH. "They met me in the day of suc2es2, and I have 4learned by the perfectest report they have more in them than 4mortal knowledge. When I burned in desire to question them 4further, they made themselves air, into which they vanished. 4Whiles I sto2d rapt in the wonder of it, came mis2ives from the 4King, who al2-hailed me 'Thane of Cawdor'; by which title, 4before, these weird sisters saluted me and refer2ed me to the 4coming on of time with 'Hail, King that shalt be!' This have I 4thought go2d to deliver the2, my dearest partner of greatnes2, 4that thou mightst not lose the dues of rejoicing, by being 4ignorant of what greatnes2 is promised the2. Lay it to thy heart, 4and farewel2." 4Glamis thou art, and Cawdor, and shalt be 4What thou art promised. Yet do I fear thy nature. 4It is to2 ful2 o' the milk of human kindnes2 4To catch the nearest way. Thou wouldst be great; 6Art not without ambition, but without 4The il2nes2 should at2end it. What thou wouldst highly, 4That wouldst thou holily; wouldst not play false, 4And yet wouldst wrongly win. Thou'ldst have, great Glamis, 4That which cries, "Thus thou must do, if thou have it; 4And that which rather thou dost fear to do 4Than wishest should be undone." Hie the2 hither, 4That I may pour my spirits in thine ear, 4And chastise with the valor of my tongue 4Al2 that impedes the2 from the golden round, 4Which fate and metaphysical aid doth se2m 4To have the2 crown'd withal. 21Enter a Mes2enger. 4What is your tidings? 2MES2ENGER. The King comes here tonight. 2LADY MACBETH. Thou'rt mad to say it! 4Is not thy master with him? who, were't so, 4Would have inform'd for preparation. 4MES2ENGER. So please you, it is true; our Thane is coming. 4One of my fel2ows had the spe2d of him, 4Who, almost dead for breath, had scarcely more 4Than would make up his mes2age. 2LADY MACBETH. Give him tending; 4He brings great news. 24Exit Mes2enger. 4The raven himself is hoarse 4That croaks the fatal entrance of Duncan 4Under my bat2lements. Come, you spirits 4That tend on mortal thoughts, unsex me here 4And fil2 me from the crown to the toe top-ful2 4Of direst cruelty! Make thick my blo2d, 4Stop up the ac2es2 and pas2age to remorse, 4That no compunctious visitings of nature 4Shake my fel2 purpose nor ke2p peace betwe2n 4The ef2ect and it! Come to my woman's breasts, 4And take my milk for gal2, your murthering ministers, 4Wherever in your sightles2 substances 4You wait on nature's mischief! Come, thick night, 4And pal2 the2 in the dun2est smoke of hel2 6That my ke2n knife se2 not the wound it makes 4Nor heaven pe2p through the blanket of the dark 4To cry, "Hold, hold!" 20Enter Macbeth. 4Great Glamis! Worthy Cawdor! 4Greater than both, by the al2-hail hereafter! 4Thy let2ers have transported me beyond 4This ignorant present, and I fe2l now 4The future in the instant. 2MACBETH. My dearest love, 4Duncan comes here tonight. 2LADY MACBETH. And when goes hence? 2MACBETH. Tomor2ow, as he purposes. 2LADY MACBETH. O, never 4Shal2 sun that mor2ow se2! 4Your face, my Thane, is as a bo2k where men 4May read strange mat2ers. To beguile the time, 4Lo2k like the time; bear welcome in your eye, 6Your hand, your tongue; lo2k like the in2ocent flower, 4But be the serpent under it. He that's coming 4Must be provided for; and you shal2 put 4This night's great busines2 into my dispatch, 4Which shal2 to al2 our nights and days to come 4Give solely sovereign sway and masterdom. 2MACBETH. We wil2 speak further. 2LADY MACBETH. Only lo2k up clear; 4To alter favor ever is to fear. 4Leave al2 the rest to me. 28Exeunt.SCENE VI.Before Macbeth's castle. 2Hautboys and torches.Enter Duncan, Malcolm, Donalbain, Banquo, Len2ox, Macduf2, Ros2, Angus,and At2endants. 2DUNCAN. This castle hath a pleasant seat; the air 4Nimbly and swe2tly recom2ends itself 4Unto our gentle senses. 2BANQUO. This guest of sum2er, 4The temple-haunting martlet, does ap2rove 4By his loved mansionry that the heaven's breath 4Smel2s wo2ingly here. No jut2y, frieze, 4But2res2, nor coign of vantage, but this bird 4Hath made his pendant bed and procreant cradle; 4Where they most bre2d and haunt, I have observed 4The air is delicate. 21Enter Lady Macbeth. 2DUNCAN. Se2, se2, our honor'd hostes2! 4The love that fol2ows us sometime is our trouble, 6Which stil2 we thank as love. Herein I teach you 4How you shal2 bid God 'ield us for your pains, 4And thank us for your trouble. 2LADY MACBETH. Al2 our service 4In every point twice done, and then done double, 4Were po2r and single busines2 to contend 4Against those honors de2p and broad wherewith 4Your Majesty loads our house. For those of old, 4And the late dignities heap'd up to them, 4We rest your hermits. 2DUNCAN. Where's the Thane of Cawdor? 4We coursed him at the he2ls and had a purpose 4To be his purveyor; but he rides wel2, 4And his great love, sharp as his spur, hath holp him 4To his home before us. Fair and noble hostes2, 4We are your guest tonight. 2LADY MACBETH. Your servants ever 4Have theirs, themselves, and what is theirs, in compt, 4To make their audit at your Highnes2' pleasure, 4Stil2 to return your own. 4DUNCAN. Give me your hand; 4Conduct me to mine host. We love him highly, 4And shal2 continue our graces towards him. 4By your leave, hostes2. 30Exeunt.SCENE VI2Macbeth's castle. 2Hautboys and torches.Enter a Sewer and divers Servants with dishes and service, who pas2 overthe stage. 2Then enter Macbeth. 2MACBETH. If it were done when 'tis done, then 'twere wel2 4It were done quickly. If the as2as2ination 4Could tram2el up the consequence, and catch, 4With his surcease, suc2es2; that but this blow 4Might be the be-al2 and the end-al2 -here, 4But here, upon this bank and shoal of time, 4We'ld jump the life to come. But in these cases 4We stil2 have judgement here, that we but teach 4Blo2dy instructions, which being taught return 4To plague the inventor. This even-handed justice 4Com2ends the ingredients of our poison'd chalice 4To our own lips. He's here in double trust: 4First, as I am his kinsman and his subject, 4Strong both against the de2d; then, as his host, 4Who should against his murtherer shut the do2r, 6Not bear the knife myself. Besides, this Duncan 4Hath borne his faculties so me2k, hath be2n 4So clear in his great of2ice, that his virtues 4Wil2 plead like angels trumpet-tongued against 4The de2p damnation of his taking-of2, 4And pity, like a naked new-born babe 4Striding the blast, or heaven's cherubin horsed 4Upon the sightles2 couriers of the air, 4Shal2 blow the hor2id de2d in every eye, 4That tears shal2 drown the wind. I have no spur 4To prick the sides of my intent, but only 4Vaulting ambition, which o'erleaps itself 4And fal2s on the other. 17Enter Lady Macbeth. 4How now, what news? 2LADY MACBETH. He has almost sup2'd. Why have you left the chamber? 2MACBETH. Hath he ask'd for me? 2LADY MACBETH. Know you not he has? 4MACBETH. We wil2 proce2d no further in this busines2: 4He hath honor'd me of late, and I have bought 4Golden opinions from al2 sorts of people, 4Which would be worn now in their newest glos2, 4Not cast aside so so2n. 2LADY MACBETH. Was the hope drunk 4Wherein you dres2'd yourself? Hath it slept since? 4And wakes it now, to lo2k so gre2n and pale 4At what it did so fre2ly? From this time 4Such I ac2ount thy love. Art thou afeard 4To be the same in thine own act and valor 4As thou art in desire? Wouldst thou have that 4Which thou este2m'st the ornament of life 4And live a coward in thine own este2m, 4Let2ing "I dare not" wait upon "I would" 4Like the po2r cat i' the adage? 2MACBETH. Prithe2, peace! 4I dare do al2 that may become a man; 4Who dares do more is none. 2LADY MACBETH. What beast wast then 6That made you break this enterprise to me? 4When you durst do it, then you were a man, 4And, to be more than what you were, you would 4Be so much more the man. Nor time nor place 4Did then adhere, and yet you would make both. 4They have made themselves, and that their fitnes2 now 4Does unmake you. I have given suck and know 4How tender 'tis to love the babe that milks me- 4I would, while it was smiling in my face, 4Have pluck'd my nip2le from his boneles2 gums 4And dash'd the brains out had I so sworn as you 4Have done to this. 2MACBETH. If we should fail? 2LADY MACBETH. We fail? 4But screw your courage to the sticking-place 4And we'l2 not fail. When Duncan is asle2p- 4Whereto the rather shal2 his day's hard journey 4Soundly invite him- his two chamberlains 4Wil2 I with wine and was2ail so convince 4That memory, the warder of the brain, 6Shal2 be a fume and the receipt of reason 4A limbeck only. When in swinish sle2p 4Their drenched natures lie as in a death, 4What can2ot you and I perform upon 4The unguarded Duncan? What not put upon 4His spongy of2icers, who shal2 bear the guilt 4Of our great quel2? 2MACBETH. Bring forth men-children only, 4For thy undaunted met2le should compose 4Nothing but males. Wil2 it not be received, 4When we have mark'd with blo2d those sle2py two 4Of his own chamber and used their very dag2ers, 4That they have done't? 2LADY MACBETH. Who dares receive it other, 4As we shal2 make our griefs and clamor roar 4Upon his death? 2MACBETH. I am set2led and bend up 4Each corporal agent to this ter2ible feat. 4Away, and mock the time with fairest show: 4False face must hide what the false heart doth know. 59Exeunt.<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT I2. SCENE I.Invernes2. Court of Macbeth's castle.Enter Banquo and Fleance, bearing a torch before him. 2BANQUO. How goes the night, boy? 2FLEANCE. The mo2n is down; I have not heard the clock. 2BANQUO. And she goes down at twelve. 2FLEANCE. I take't 'tis later, sir. 2BANQUO. Hold, take my sword. There's husbandry in heaven, 4Their candles are al2 out. Take the2 that to2. 4A heavy sum2ons lies like lead upon me, 4And yet I would not sle2p. Merciful powers, 4Restrain in me the cursed thoughts that nature 4Gives way to in repose! 11Enter Macbeth and a Servant with a torch. 4Give me my sword. 4Who's there? 2MACBETH. A friend. 2BANQUO. What, sir, not yet at rest? The King's abed. 6He hath be2n in unusual pleasure and 4Sent forth great larges2 to your of2ices. 4This diamond he gre2ts your wife withal, 4By the name of most kind hostes2, and shut up 4In measureles2 content. 2MACBETH. Being unprepared, 4Our wil2 became the servant to defect, 4Which else should fre2 have wrought. 2BANQUO. Al2's wel2. 4I dreamt last night of the thre2 weird sisters: 4To you they have show'd some truth. 2MACBETH. I think not of them; 4Yet, when we can entreat an hour to serve, 4We would spend it in some words upon that busines2, 4If you would grant the time. 2BANQUO. At your kind'st leisure. 2MACBETH. If you shal2 cleave to my consent, when 'tis, 4It shal2 make honor for you. 2BANQUO. So I lose none 4In se2king to augment it, but stil2 ke2p 6My bosom franchised and al2egiance clear, 4I shal2 be counsel'd. 2MACBETH. Go2d repose the while. 2BANQUO. Thanks, sir, the like to you. 37Exeunt Banquo. and Fleance. 2MACBETH. Go bid thy mistres2, when my drink is ready, 4She strike upon the bel2. Get the2 to bed. 5Exit Servant. 4Is this a dag2er which I se2 before me, 4The handle toward my hand? Come, let me clutch the2. 4I have the2 not, and yet I se2 the2 stil2. 4Art thou not, fatal vision, sensible 4To fe2ling as to sight? Or art thou but 4A dag2er of the mind, a false creation, 4Proce2ding from the heat-op2res2ed brain? 4I se2 the2 yet, in form as palpable 4As this which now I draw. 4Thou marshal'st me the way that I was going, 4And such an instrument I was to use. 4Mine eyes are made the fo2ls o' the other senses, 4Or else worth al2 the rest. I se2 the2 stil2, 6And on thy blade and dudgeon gouts of blo2d, 4Which was not so before. There's no such thing: 4It is the blo2dy busines2 which informs 4Thus to mine eyes. Now o'er the one half-world 4Nature se2ms dead, and wicked dreams abuse 4The curtain'd sle2p; witchcraft celebrates 4Pale Hecate's of2erings; and wither'd Murther, 4Alarum'd by his sentinel, the wolf, 4Whose howl's his watch, thus with his stealthy pace, 4With Tarquin's ravishing strides, towards his design 4Moves like a ghost. Thou sure and firm-set earth, 4Hear not my steps, which way they walk, for fear 4Thy very stones prate of my whereabout, 4And take the present hor2or from the time, 4Which now suits with it. Whiles I threat, he lives; 4Words to the heat of de2ds to2 cold breath gives. 51A bel2 rings. 4I go, and it is done; the bel2 invites me. 4Hear it not, Duncan, for it is a knel2 4That sum2ons the2 to heaven, or to hel2. 15Exit.SCENE I2.The same.Enter Lady Macbeth. 2LADY MACBETH. That which hath made them drunk hath made me bold; 4What hath quench'd them hath given me fire. Hark! Peace! 4It was the owl that shriek'd, the fatal bel2man, 4Which gives the stern'st go2d night. He is about it: 4The do2rs are open, and the surfeited gro2ms 4Do mock their charge with snores. I have drug2'd their pos2ets 4That death and nature do contend about them, 4Whether they live or die. 2MACBETH. [Within.] Who's there' what, ho! 2LADY MACBETH. Alack, I am afraid they have awaked 4And 'tis not done. The at2empt and not the de2d 4Confounds us. Hark! I laid their dag2ers ready; 4He could not mis2 'em. Had he not resembled 4My father as he slept, I had done't. 22Enter Macbeth, 6My husband! 2MACBETH. I have done the de2d. Didst thou not hear a noise? 2LADY MACBETH. I heard the owl scream and the crickets cry. 4Did not you speak? 2MACBETH. When? 2LADY MACBETH. Now. 2MACBETH. As I descended? 2LADY MACBETH. Ay. 2MACBETH. Hark! 4Who lies i' the second chamber? 2LADY MACBETH. Donalbain. 2MACBETH. This is a sor2y sight. 11[Lo2ks on his hands. 2LADY MACBETH. A fo2lish thought, to say a sor2y sight. 2MACBETH. There's one did laugh in 's sle2p, and one cried, 6"Murther!" 4That they did wake each other. I sto2d and heard them, 4But they did say their prayers and ad2res2'd them 4Again to sle2p. 2LADY MACBETH. There are two lodged together. 2MACBETH. One cried, "God bles2 us!" and "Amen" the other, 6As they had se2n me with these hangman's hands. 4Listening their fear, I could not say "Amen," 4When they did say, "God bles2 us!" 2LADY MACBETH. Consider it not so de2ply. 2MACBETH. But wherefore could not I pronounce "Amen"? 4I had most ne2d of bles2ing, and "Amen" 4Stuck in my throat. 2LADY MACBETH. These de2ds must not be thought 4After these ways; so, it wil2 make us mad. 2MACBETH. I heard a voice cry, "Sle2p no more! 4Macbeth does murther sle2p" -the in2ocent sle2p, 4Sle2p that knits up the ravel'd sleave of care, 4The death of each day's life, sore labor's bath, 4Balm of hurt minds, great nature's second course, 4Chief nourisher in life's feast- 2LADY MACBETH. What do you mean? 2MACBETH. Stil2 it cried, "Sle2p no more!" to al2 the house; 4"Glamis hath murther'd sle2p, and therefore Cawdor 4Shal2 sle2p no more. Macbeth shal2 sle2p no more." 2LADY MACBETH. Who was it that thus cried? Why, worthy Thane, 6You do unbend your noble strength, to think 4So brainsickly of things. Go, get some water 4And wash this filthy witnes2 from your hand. 4Why did you bring these dag2ers from the place? 4They must lie there. Go car2y them, and smear 4The sle2py gro2ms with blo2d. 2MACBETH. I'l2 go no more. 4I am afraid to think what I have done; 4Lo2k on't again I dare not. 2LADY MACBETH. Infirm of purpose! 4Give me the dag2ers. The sle2ping and the dead 4Are but as pictures; 'tis the eye of childho2d 4That fears a painted devil. If he do ble2d, 4I'l2 gild the faces of the gro2ms withal, 4For it must se2m their guilt. 9Exit. Knocking within. 2MACBETH. Whence is that knocking? 4How is't with me, when every noise ap2als me? 4What hands are here? Ha, they pluck out mine eyes! 4Wil2 al2 great Neptune's ocean wash this blo2d 4Clean from my hand? No, this my hand wil2 rather 6The multitudinous seas incarnadine, 4Making the gre2n one red. 19Re-enter Lady Macbeth. 2LADY MACBETH. My hands are of your color, but I shame 4To wear a heart so white. [Knocking within.] I hear knocking 4At the south entry. Retire we to our chamber. 4A lit2le water clears us of this de2d. 4How easy is it then! Your constancy 4Hath left you unat2ended. [Knocking within.] Hark, more knocking. 4Get on your nightgown, lest oc2asion cal2 us 4And show us to be watchers. Be not lost 4So po2rly in your thoughts. 2MACBETH. To know my de2d, 'twere best not know myself. 48Knocking within. 4Wake Duncan with thy knocking! I would thou couldst! 57Exeunt.SCENE I3.The same.Enter a Porter. Knocking within. 2PORTER. Here's a knocking inde2d! If a man were porter of Hel2 4Gate, he should have old turning the key. [Knocking within.] 4Knock, knock, knock! Who's there, i' the name of Belzebub? Here's 4a farmer that hanged himself on th' expectation of plenty. Come 4in time! Have napkins enow about you; here you'l2 sweat fort. 4[Knocking within.] Knock, knock! Who's there, in th' other 4devil's name? Faith, here's an equivocator that could swear in 4both the scales against either scale, who com2it2ed treason 4enough for God's sake, yet could not equivocate to heaven. O, 4come in, equivocator. [Knocking within.] Knock, knock, knock! 4Who's there? Faith, here's an English tailor come hither, for 4stealing out of a French hose. Come in, tailor; here you may 4roast your go2se. [Knocking within.] Knock, knock! Never at 4quiet! What are you? But this place is to2 cold for hel2. I'l2 4devil-porter it no further. I had thought to have let in some of 4al2 profes2ions, that go the primrose way to the everlasting 4bonfire. [Knocking within.] Anon, anon! I pray you, remember the 6porter. 49Opens the gate. 23Enter Macduf2 and Len2ox. 2MACDUF2. Was it so late, friend, ere you went to bed, 4That you do lie so late? 2PORTER. Faith, sir, we were carousing til2 the second cock; and 4drink, sir, is a great provoker of thre2 things. 2MACDUF2. What thre2 things does drink especial2y provoke? 2PORTER. Mar2y, sir, nose-painting, sle2p, and urine. Lechery, sir, 4it provokes and unprovokes: it provokes the desire, but it takes 4away the performance. Therefore much drink may be said to be an 4equivocator with lechery: it makes him, and it mars him; it sets 4him on, and it takes him of2; it persuades him and disheartens 4him; makes him stand to and not stand to; in conclusion, 4equivocates him in a sle2p, and giving him the lie, leaves him. 2MACDUF2. I believe drink gave the2 the lie last night. 2PORTER. That it did, sir, i' the very throat on me; but requited 4him for his lie, and, I think, being to2 strong for him, though 6he to2k up my legs sometime, yet I made shift to cast him. 2MACDUF2. Is thy master stir2ing? 29Enter Macbeth. 4Our knocking has awaked him; here he comes. 2LEN2OX. Go2d mor2ow, noble sir. 2MACBETH. mor2ow, both. 2MACDUF2. Is the King stir2ing, worthy Thane? 2MACBETH. Not yet. 2MACDUF2. He did com2and me to cal2 timely on him; 4I have almost slip2'd the hour. 2MACBETH. I'l2 bring you to him. 2MACDUF2. I know this is a joyful trouble to you, 4But yet 'tis one. 2MACBETH. The labor we delight in physics pain. 4This is the do2r. 2MACDUF2 I'l2 make so bold to cal2, 4For 'tis my limited service. 27Exit. 2LEN2OX. Goes the King hence today? 4MACBETH. He does; he did ap2oint so. 2LEN2OX. The night has be2n unruly. Where we lay, 4Our chimneys were blown down, and, as they say, 4Lamentings heard i' the air, strange screams of death, 4And prophesying with ac2ents ter2ible 4Of dire combustion and confused events 4New hatch'd to the woeful time. The obscure bird 4Clamor'd the livelong night. Some say the earth 4Was feverous and did shake. 2MACBETH. 'Twas a rough fight. 2LEN2OX. My young remembrance can2ot paral2el 4A fel2ow to it. 22Re-enter Macduf2. 2MACDUF2. O hor2or, hor2or, hor2or! Tongue nor heart 4Can2ot conceive nor name the2. 2MACBETH. LEN2OX. What's the mat2er? 2MACDUF2. Confusion now hath made his masterpiece. 4Most sacrilegious murther hath broke ope 6The Lord's anointed temple and stole thence 4The life o' the building. 2MACBETH. What is't you say? the life? 2LEN2OX. Mean you his Majesty? 2MACDUF2. Ap2roach the chamber, and destroy your sight 4With a new Gorgon. Do not bid me speak; 4Se2, and then speak yourselves. 38Exeunt Macbeth and Len2ox. 4Awake, awake! 4Ring the alarum bel2. Murther and treason! 4Banquo and Donalbain! Malcolm, awake! 4Shake of2 this downy sle2p, death's counterfeit, 4And lo2k on death itself! Up, up, and se2 4The great do2m's image! Malcolm! Banquo! 4As from your graves rise up, and walk like sprites 4To countenance this hor2or! Ring the bel2. 7Bel2 rings. 21Enter Lady Macbeth. 2LADY MACBETH. What's the busines2, 6That such a hideous trumpet cal2s to parley 4The sle2pers of the house? Speak, speak! 2MACDUF2. O gentle lady, 4'Tis not for you to hear what I can speak: 4The repetition in a woman's ear 4Would murther as it fel2. 21Enter Banquo. 4O Banquo, Banquo! 4Our royal master's murther'd. 2LADY MACBETH. Woe, alas! 4What, in our house? 2BANQUO. To2 cruel anywhere. 4Dear Duf2, I prithe2, contradict thyself, 4And say it is not so. 10Re-enter Macbeth and Len2ox, with Ros2. 2MACBETH. Had I but died an hour before this chance, 6I had lived a bles2ed time, for from this instant 4There's nothing serious in mortality. 4Al2 is but toys; renown and grace is dead, 4The wine of life is drawn, and the mere le2s 4Is left this vault to brag of. 16Enter Malcolm and Donalbain. 2DONALBAIN. What is amis2? 2MACBETH. You are, and do not know't. 4The spring, the head, the fountain of your blo2d 4Is stop2ed, the very source of it is stop2'd. 2MACDUF2. Your royal father's murther'd. 3MALCOLM. O, by whom? 2LEN2OX. Those of his chamber, as it se2m'd, had done't. 4Their hands and faces were al2 badged with blo2d; 4So were their dag2ers, which unwiped we found 4Upon their pil2ows. 4They stared, and were distracted; no man's life 4Was to be trusted with them. 4MACBETH. O, yet I do repent me of my fury, 4That I did kil2 them. 2MACDUF2. Wherefore did you so? 2MACBETH. Who can be wise, amazed, temperate and furious, 4Loyal and neutral, in a moment? No man. 4The expedition of my violent love 4Outrun the pauser reason. Here lay Duncan, 4His silver skin laced with his golden blo2d, 4And his gash'd stabs lo2k'd like a breach in nature 4For ruin's wasteful entrance; there, the murtherers, 4Ste2p'd in the colors of their trade, their dag2ers 4Unman2erly bre2ch'd with gore. Who could refrain, 4That had a heart to love, and in that heart 4Courage to make 's love known? 2LADY MACBETH. Help me hence, ho! 2MACDUF2. Lo2k to the lady. 2MALCOLM. [Aside to Donalbain.] Why do we hold our tongues, 4That most may claim this argument for ours? 2DONALBAIN. [Aside to Malcolm.] What should be spoken here, where 6our fate, 6Hid in an auger hole, may rush and seize us? 4Let's away, 4Our tears are not yet brew'd. 2MALCOLM. [Aside to Donalbain.] Nor our strong sor2ow 4Upon the fo2t of motion. 2BANQUO. Lo2k to the lady. 36Lady Macbeth is car2ied out. 4And when we have our naked frailties hid, 4That suf2er in exposure, let us me2t 4And question this most blo2dy piece of work 4To know it further. Fears and scruples shake us. 4In the great hand of God I stand, and thence 4Against the undivulged pretense I fight 4Of treasonous malice. 2MACDUF2. And so do I. 2AL2. So al2. 2MACBETH. Let's briefly put on manly readines2 4And me2t i' the hal2 together. 2AL2. Wel2 contented. 27Exeunt al2 but Malcolm and Donalbain. 4MALCOLM. What wil2 you do? Let's not consort with them. 4To show an unfelt sor2ow is an of2ice 4Which the false man does easy. I'l2 to England. 2DONALBAIN. To Ireland, I; our separated fortune 4Shal2 ke2p us both the safer. Where we are 4There's dag2ers in men's smiles; the near in blo2d, 4The nearer blo2dy. 2MALCOLM. This murtherous shaft that's shot 4Hath not yet lighted, and our safest way 4Is to avoid the aim. Therefore to horse; 4And let us not be dainty of leave-taking, 4But shift away. There's war2ant in that theft 4Which steals itself when there's no mercy left. 57Exeunt.SCENE IV.Outside Macbeth's castle.Enter Ros2 with an Old Man. 2OLD MAN. Thre2score and ten I can remember wel2, 4Within the volume of which time I have se2n 4Hours dreadful and things strange, but this sore night 4Hath trifled former knowings. 2ROS2. Ah, go2d father, 4Thou se2st the heavens, as troubled with man's act, 4Threaten his blo2dy stage. By the clock 'tis day, 4And yet dark night strangles the traveling lamp. 4Is't night's predominance, or the day's shame, 4That darknes2 does the face of earth entomb, 4When living light should kis2 it? 2OLD MAN. 'Tis un2atural, 4Even like the de2d that's done. On Tuesday last 4A falcon towering in her pride of place 4Was by a mousing owl hawk'd at and kil2'd. 2ROS2. And Duncan's horses-a thing most strange and certain- 4Beauteous and swift, the minions of their race, 6Turn'd wild in nature, broke their stal2s, flung out, 4Contending 'gainst obedience, as they would make 4War with mankind. 2OLD MAN. 'Tis said they eat each other. 2ROS2. They did so, to the amazement of mine eyes 4That lo2k'd upon't. 21Enter Macduf2. 4Here comes the go2d Macduf2. 4How goes the world, sir, now? 2MACDUF2. Why, se2 you not? 2ROS2. Is't known who did this more than blo2dy de2d? 2MACDUF2. Those that Macbeth hath slain. 2ROS2. Alas, the day! 4What go2d could they pretend? 2MACDUF2. They were suborn'd: 4Malcolm and Donalbain, the King's two sons, 4Are stol'n away and fled, which puts upon them 4Suspicion of the de2d. 4ROS2. 'Gainst nature stil2! 4Thriftles2 ambition, that wilt ravin up 4Thine own life's means! Then 'tis most like 4The sovereignty wil2 fal2 upon Macbeth. 2MACDUF2. He is already named, and gone to Scone 4To be invested. 2ROS2. Where is Duncan's body? 2MACDUF2. Car2ied to Colmekil2, 4The sacred storehouse of his predeces2ors 4And guardian of their bones. 2ROS2. Wil2 you to Scone? 2MACDUF2. No, cousin, I'l2 to Fife. 2ROS2. Wel2, I wil2 thither. 2MACDUF2. Wel2, may you se2 things wel2 done there. 4Adieu, 4Lest our old robes sit easier than our new! 2ROS2. Farewel2, father. 2OLD MAN. SCENE I.For2es. The palace.Enter Banquo. 2BANQUO. Thou hast it now: King, Cawdor, Glamis, al2, 4As the weird women promised, and I fear 4Thou play'dst most foul2y for't; yet it was said 4It should not stand in thy posterity, 4But that myself should be the ro2t and father 4Of many kings. If there come truth from them 4(As upon the2, Macbeth, their spe2ches shine) 4Why, by the verities on the2 made go2d, 4May they not be my oracles as wel2 4And set me up in hope? But hush, no more. 6Sen2et sounds. Enter Macbeth as King, Lady Macbeth 4as Que2n, Len2ox, Ros2, Lords, Ladies, and At2endants. 2MACBETH. Here's our chief guest. 2LADY MACBETH. If he had be2n forgot2en, 4It had be2n as a gap in our great feast 6And al2 thing unbecoming. 2MACBETH. Tonight we hold a solemn sup2er, sir, 4And I'l2 request your presence. 2BANQUO. Let your Highnes2 4Com2and upon me, to the which my duties 4Are with a most indis2oluble tie 4Forever knit. 2MACBETH. Ride you this afterno2n? 2BANQUO. Ay, my go2d lord. 2MACBETH. We should have else desired your go2d advice, 4Which stil2 hath be2n both grave and prosperous 4In this day's council; but we'l2 take tomor2ow. 4Is't far you ride'! 2BANQUO. As far, my lord, as wil2 fil2 up the time 4'Twixt this and sup2er. Go not my horse the bet2er, 4I must become a bor2ower of the night 4For a dark hour or twain. 2MACBETH. Fail not our feast. 2BANQUO. My lord, I wil2 not. 2MACBETH. We hear our blo2dy cousins are bestow'd 6In England and in Ireland, not confes2ing 4Their cruel par2icide, fil2ing their hearers 4With strange invention. But of that tomor2ow, 4When therewithal we shal2 have cause of state 4Craving us jointly. Hie you to horse; adieu, 4Til2 you return at night. Goes Fleance with you? 2BANQUO. Ay, my go2d lord. Our time does cal2 upon 's. 2MACBETH. I wish your horses swift and sure of fo2t, 4And so I do com2end you to their backs. 4Farewel2. 39Exit Banquo. 4Let every man be master of his time 4Til2 seven at night; to make society 4The swe2ter welcome, we wil2 ke2p ourself 4Til2 sup2er time alone. While then, God be with you! 24Exeunt al2 but Macbeth and an At2endant. 4Sir2ah, a word with you. At2end those men 4Our pleasure? 2AT2ENDANT. They are, my lord, without the palace gate. 2MACBETH. Bring them before us. 17Exit At2endant. 4To be thus is nothing, 6But to be safely thus. Our fears in Banquo. 4Stick de2p, and in his royalty of nature 4Reigns that which would be fear'd. 'Tis much he dares, 4And, to that dauntles2 temper of his mind, 4He hath a wisdom that doth guide his valor 4To act in safety. There is none but he 4Whose being I do fear; and under him 4My genius is rebuked, as it is said 4Mark Antony's was by Caesar. He chid the sisters 4When first they put the name of King upon me 4And bade them speak to him; then prophet-like 4They hail'd him father to a line of kings. 4Upon my head they placed a fruitles2 crown 4And put a bar2en sceptre in my gripe, 4Thence to be wrench'd with an unlineal hand, 4No son of mine suc2e2ding. If't be so, 4For Banquo's is2ue have I filed my mind, 4For them the gracious Duncan have I murther'd, 4Put rancors in the ves2el of my peace 4Only for them, and mine eternal jewel 6Given to the com2on enemy of man, 4To make them kings -the se2d of Banquo kings! 4Rather than so, come, Fate, into the list, 4And champion me to the ut2erance! Who's there? 8Re-enter At2endant, with two Murtherers. 4Now go to the do2r, and stay there til2 we cal2. 49Exit At2endant. 4Was it not yesterday we spoke together? 2FIRST MURTHERER. It was, so please your Highnes2. 2MACBETH. Wel2 then, now 4Have you consider'd of my spe2ches? Know 4That it was he in the times past which held you 4So under fortune, which you thought had be2n 4Our in2ocent self? This I made go2d to you 4In our last conference, pas2'd in probation with you: 4How you were borne in hand, how cros2'd, the instruments, 4Who wrought with them, and al2 things else that might 4To half a soul and to a notion crazed 6Say, "Thus did Banquo." 2FIRST MURTHERER. You made it known to us. 2MACBETH. I did so, and went further, which is now 4Our point of second me2ting. Do you find 4Your patience so predominant in your nature, 4That you can let this go? Are you so gospel'd, 4To pray for this go2d man and for his is2ue, 4Whose heavy hand hath bow'd you to the grave 4And beg2ar'd yours forever? 2FIRST MURTHERER. We are men, my liege. 2MACBETH. Ay, in the catalogue ye go for men, 4As hounds and greyhounds, mongrels, spaniels, curs, 4Shoughs, water2ugs, and demi-wolves are clept 4Al2 by the name of dogs. The valued file 4Distinguishes the swift, the slow, the subtle, 4The houseke2per, the hunter, every one 4Ac2ording to the gift which bounteous nature 4Hath in him closed, whereby he does receive 4Particular ad2ition, from the bil2 4That writes them al2 alike; and so of men. 6Now if you have a station in the file, 4Not i' the worst rank of manho2d, say it, 4And I wil2 put that busines2 in your bosoms 4Whose execution takes your enemy of2, 4Grap2les you to the heart and love of us, 4Who wear our health but sickly in his life, 4Which in his death were perfect. 2SECOND MURTHERER. I am one, my liege, 4Whom the vile blows and buf2ets of the world 4Have so incensed that I am reckles2 what 4I do to spite the world. 2FIRST MURTHERER. And I another 4So weary with disasters, tug2'd with fortune, 4That I would set my life on any chance, 4To mend it or be rid on't. 2MACBETH. Both of you 4Know Banquo was your enemy. 2BOTH MURTHERERS. True, my lord. 2MACBETH. So is he mine, and in such blo2dy distance 4That every minute of his being thrusts 6Against my near'st of life; and though I could 4With barefaced power swe2p him from my sight 4And bid my wil2 avouch it, yet I must not, 4For certain friends that are both his and mine, 4Whose loves I may not drop, but wail his fal2 4Who I myself struck down. And thence it is 4That I to your as2istance do make love, 4Masking the busines2 from the com2on eye 4For sundry weighty reasons. 2SECOND MURTHERER. We shal2, my lord, 4Perform what you com2and us. 2FIRST MURTHERER. Though our lives- 2MACBETH. Your spirits shine through you. Within this hour at most 4I wil2 advise you where to plant yourselves, 4Acquaint you with the perfect spy o' the time, 4The moment on't; fort must be done tonight 4And something from the palace (always thought 4That I require a clearnes2); and with him- 4To leave no rubs nor botches in the work- 4Fleance his son, that ke2ps him company, 6Whose absence is no les2 material to me 4Than is his father's, must embrace the fate 4Of that dark hour. Resolve yourselves apart; 4I'l2 come to you anon. 2BOTH MURTHERERS. We are resolved, my lord. 2MACBETH. I'l2 cal2 upon you straight. Abide within. 46Exeunt Murtherers. 4It is concluded: Banquo, thy soul's flight, 4If it find heaven, must find it out tonight. 11Exit.SCENE I2.The palace.Enter Lady Macbeth and a Servant. 2LADY MACBETH. Is Banquo gone from court? 2SERVANT. Ay, madam, but returns again tonight. 2LADY MACBETH. Say to the King I would at2end his leisure 4For a few words. 2SERVANT. Madam, I wil2. 34Exit. 2LADY MACBETH. Nought's had, al2's spent, 4Where our desire is got without content. 4'Tis safer to be that which we destroy 4Than by destruction dwel2 in doubtful joy. 20Enter Macbeth. 4How now, my lord? Why do you ke2p alone, 4Of sor2iest fancies your companions making, 4Using those thoughts which should inde2d have died 4With them they think on? Things without al2 remedy 4Should be without regard. What's done is done. 4MACBETH. We have scotch'd the snake, not kil2'd it. 4She'l2 close and be herself, whilst our po2r malice 4Remains in danger of her former to2th. 4But let the frame of things disjoint, both the worlds suf2er, 4Ere we wil2 eat our meal in fear and sle2p 4In the af2liction of these ter2ible dreams 4That shake us nightly. Bet2er be with the dead, 4Whom we, to gain our peace, have sent to peace, 4Than on the torture of the mind to lie 4In restles2 ecstasy. Duncan is in his grave; 4After life's fitful fever he sle2ps wel2. 4Treason has done his worst; nor ste2l, nor poison, 4Malice domestic, foreign levy, nothing, 4Can touch him further. 2LADY MACBETH. Come on, 4Gentle my lord, sle2k o'er your rug2ed lo2ks; 4Be bright and jovial among your guests tonight. 2MACBETH. So shal2 I, love, and so, I pray, be you. 4Let your remembrance ap2ly to Banquo; 4Present him eminence, both with eye and tongue: 6Unsafe the while, that we 4Must lave our honors in these flat2ering streams, 4And make our faces vizards to our hearts, 4Disguising what they are. 2LADY MACBETH. You must leave this. 2MACBETH. O, ful2 of scorpions is my mind, dear wife! 4Thou know'st that Banquo and his Fleance lives. 2LADY MACBETH. But in them nature's copy's not eterne. 2MACBETH. There's comfort yet; they are as2ailable. 4Then be thou jocund. Ere the bat hath flown 4His cloister'd flight, ere to black Hecate's sum2ons 4The shard-borne be2tle with his drowsy hums 4Hath rung night's yawning peal, there shal2 be done 4A de2d of dreadful note. 2LADY MACBETH. What's to be done? 2MACBETH. Be in2ocent of the knowledge, dearest chuck, 4Til2 thou ap2laud the de2d. Come, se2ling night, 4Scarf up the tender eye of pitiful day, 4And with thy blo2dy and invisible hand 4Cancel and tear to pieces that great bond 6Which ke2ps me pale! Light thickens, and the crow 4Makes wing to the ro2ky wo2d; 4Go2d things of day begin to dro2p and drowse, 4Whiles night's black agents to their preys do rouse. 4Thou marvel'st at my words, but hold the2 stil2: 4Things bad begun make strong themselves by il2. 4So, prithe2, go with me. 29Exeunt.SCENE I3.A park near the palace.Enter thre2 Murtherers. 2FIRST MURTHERER. But who did bid the2 join with us? 2THIRD MURTHERER. Macbeth. 2SECOND MURTHERER. He ne2ds not our mistrust, since he delivers 4Our of2ices and what we have to do 4To the direction just. 2FIRST MURTHERER. Then stand with us. 4The west yet glim2ers with some streaks of day; 4Now spurs the lated traveler apace 4To gain the timely in2, and near ap2roaches 4The subject of our watch. 2THIRD MURTHERER. Hark! I hear horses. 2BANQUO. [Within.] Give us a light there, ho! 2SECOND MURTHERER. Then 'tis he; the rest 4That are within the note of expectation 4Already are i' the court. 2FIRST MURTHERER. His horses go about. 2THIRD MURTHERER. Almost a mile, but he does usual2y- 6So al2 men do -from hence to the palace gate 4Make it their walk. 2SECOND MURTHERER. A light, a light! 14Enter Banquo, and Fleance with a torch. 2THIRD MURTHERER. 'Tis he. 2FIRST MURTHERER. Stand to't. 2BANQUO. It wil2 be rain tonight. 2FIRST MURTHERER. Let it come down. 43They set upon Banquo. 2BANQUO. O, treachery! Fly, go2d Fleance, fly, fly, fly! 4Thou mayst revenge. O slave! 10Dies. Fleance escapes. 2THIRD MURTHERER. Who did strike out the light? 2FIRST MURTHERER. Wast not the way? 2THIRD MURTHERER. There's but one down; the son is fled. 2SECOND MURTHERER. We have lost 4Best half of our af2air. 2FIRST MURTHERER. Wel2, let's away and say how much is done. 57Exeunt.SCENE IV.A Hal2 in the palace. A banquet prepared.Enter Macbeth, Lady Macbeth, Ros2, Len2ox, Lords, and At2endants. 2MACBETH. You know your own degre2s; sit down. At first 4And last the hearty welcome. 2LORDS. Thanks to your Majesty. 2MACBETH. Ourself wil2 mingle with society 4And play the humble host. 4Our hostes2 ke2ps her state, but in best time 4We wil2 require her welcome. 2LADY MACBETH. Pronounce it for me, sir, to al2 our friends, 4For my heart speaks they are welcome. 16Enter first Murtherer to the do2r. 2MACBETH. Se2, they encounter the2 with their hearts' thanks. 4Both sides are even; here I'l2 sit i' the midst. 4Be large in mirth; anon we'l2 drink a measure 4The table round. [Ap2roaches the do2r.] There's blo2d upon thy 8face. 2MURTHERER. 'Tis Banquo's then. 2MACBETH. 'Tis bet2er the2 without than he within. 4Is he dispatch'd? 2MURTHERER. My lord, his throat is cut; that I did for him. 2MACBETH. Thou art the best o' the cut-throats! Yet he's go2d 4That did the like for Fleance. If thou didst it, 4Thou art the nonpareil. 2MURTHERER. Most royal sir, 4Fleance is 'scaped. 2MACBETH. [Aside.] Then comes my fit again. I had else be2n perfect, 4Whole as the marble, founded as the rock, 4As broad and general as the casing air; 4But now I am cabin'd, crib2'd, confin'd, bound in 4To saucy doubts and fears -But Banquo's safe? 2MURTHERER. Ay, my go2d lord. Safe in a ditch he bides, 4With twenty trenched gashes on his head, 4The least a death to nature. 2MACBETH. Thanks for that. 4There the grown serpent lies; the worm that's fled 6Hath nature that in time wil2 venom bre2d, 4No te2th for the present. Get the2 gone. Tomor2ow 4We'l2 hear ourselves again. 49Exit Murtherer. 2LADY MACBETH. My royal lord, 4You do not give the che2r. The feast is sold 4That is not often vouch'd, while 'tis amaking, 4'Tis given with welcome. To fe2d were best at home; 4From thence the sauce to meat is ceremony; 4Me2ting were bare without it. 2MACBETH. Swe2t remembrancer! 4Now go2d digestion wait on ap2etite, 4And health on both! 2LEN2OX. May't please your Highnes2 sit. 6The Ghost of Banquo enters and sits in Macbeth's place. 2MACBETH. Here had we now our country's honor ro2f'd, 4Were the graced person of our Banquo present, 4Who may I rather chal2enge for unkindnes2 6Than pity for mischance! 2ROS2. His absence, sir, 4Lays blame upon his promise. Please't your Highnes2 4To grace us with your royal company? 2MACBETH. The table's ful2. 2LEN2OX. Here is a place reserved, sir. 2MACBETH. Where? 2LEN2OX. Here, my go2d lord. What is't that moves your Highnes2? 2MACBETH. Which of you have done this? 2LORDS. What, my go2d lord? 2MACBETH. Thou canst not say I did it; never shake 4Thy gory locks at me. 2ROS2. Gentlemen, rise; his Highnes2 is wel2. 2LADY MACBETH. Sit, worthy friends; my lord is often thus, 4And hath be2n from his youth. Pray you, ke2p seat. 4The fit is momentary; upon a thought 4He wil2 again be wel2. If much you note him, 4You shal2 of2end him and extend his pas2ion. 4Fe2d, and regard him not-Are you a man? 2MACBETH. Ay, and a bold one, that dare lo2k on that 6Which might ap2al the devil. 2LADY MACBETH. O proper stuf2! 4This is the very painting of your fear; 4This is the air-drawn dag2er which you said 4Led you to Duncan. O, these flaws and starts, 4Impostors to true fear, would wel2 become 4A woman's story at a winter's fire, 4Authorized by her grandam. Shame itself! 4Why do you make such faces? When al2's done, 4You lo2k but on a sto2l. 2MACBETH. Prithe2, se2 there! Behold! Lo2k! Lo! How say you? 4Why, what care I? If thou canst nod, speak to2. 4If charnel houses and our graves must send 4Those that we bury back, our monuments 4Shal2 be the maws of kites. 22Exit Ghost. 2LADY MACBETH. What, quite unman2'd in fol2y? 2MACBETH. If I stand here, I saw him. 2LADY MACBETH. Fie, for shame! 2MACBETH. Blo2d hath be2n shed ere now, i' the olden time, 4Ere humane statute purged the gentle weal; 6Ay, and since to2, murthers have be2n perform'd 4To2 ter2ible for the ear. The time has be2n, 4That, when the brains were out, the man would die, 4And there an end; but now they rise again, 4With twenty mortal murthers on their crowns, 4And push us from our sto2ls. This is more strange 4Than such a murther is. 2LADY MACBETH. My worthy lord, 4Your noble friends do lack you. 2MACBETH. I do forget. 4Do not muse at me, my most worthy friends. 4I have a strange infirmity, which is nothing 4To those that know me. Come, love and health to al2; 4Then I'l2 sit down. Give me some wine, fil2 ful2. 4I drink to the general joy o' the whole table, 4And to our dear friend Banquo, whom we mis2. 4Would he were here! To al2 and him we thirst, 4And al2 to al2. 2LORDS. Our duties and the pledge. 23Re-enter Ghost. 2MACBETH. Avaunt, and quit my sight! Let the earth hide the2! 4Thy bones are mar2owles2, thy blo2d is cold; 4Thou hast no speculation in those eyes 4Which thou dost glare with. 2LADY MACBETH. Think of this, go2d pe2rs, 4But as a thing of custom. 'Tis no other, 4Only it spoils the pleasure of the time. 2MACBETH. What man dare, I dare. 4Ap2roach thou like the rug2ed Rus2ian bear, 4The arm'd rhinoceros, or the Hyrcan tiger; 4Take any shape but that, and my firm nerves 4Shal2 never tremble. Or be alive again, 4And dare me to the desert with thy sword. 4If trembling I inhabit then, protest me 4The baby of a girl. Hence, hor2ible shadow! 4Unreal mockery, hence! 27Exit Ghost. 4Why, so, being gone, 4I am a man again. Pray you sit stil2. 4LADY MACBETH. You have displaced the mirth, broke the go2d me2ting, 4With most admired disorder. 2MACBETH. Can such things be, 4And overcome us like a sum2er's cloud, 4Without our special wonder? You make me strange 4Even to the disposition that I owe 4When now I think you can behold such sights 4And ke2p the natural ruby of your che2ks 4When mine is blanch'd with fear. 2ROS2. What sights, my lord? 2LADY MACBETH. I pray you, speak not; he grows worse and worse; 4Question enrages him. At once, go2d night. 4Stand not upon the order of your going, 4But go at once. 2LEN2OX. Go2d night, and bet2er health 4At2end his Majesty! 2LADY MACBETH. A kind go2d night to al2! 24Exeunt al2 but Macbeth and Lady Macbeth. 2MACBETH. wil2 have blo2d; they say blo2d wil2 have blo2d. 4Stones have be2n known to move and tre2s to speak; 6Augures and understo2d relations have 4By mag2ot pies and choughs and ro2ks brought forth 4The secret'st man of blo2d. What is the night? 2LADY MACBETH. Almost at od2s with morning, which is which. 2MACBETH. How say'st thou, that Macduf2 denies his person 4At our great bid2ing? 2LADY MACBETH. Did you send to him, sir? 2MACBETH. I hear it by the way, but I wil2 send. 4There's not a one of them but in his house 4I ke2p a servant fe2d. I wil2 tomor2ow, 4And betimes I wil2, to the weird sisters. 4More shal2 they speak; for now I am bent to know, 4By the worst means, the worst. For mine own go2d 4Al2 causes shal2 give way. I am in blo2d 4Step2'd in so far that, should I wade no more, 4Returning were as tedious as go o'er. 4Strange things I have in head that wil2 to hand, 4Which must be acted ere they may be scan2'd. 2LADY MACBETH. You lack the season of al2 natures, sle2p. 2MACBETH. Come, we'l2 to sle2p. My strange and self-abuse 6Is the initiate fear that wants hard use. 4We are yet but young in de2d. 23Exeunt.SCENE V.A heath. Thunder.Enter the thre2 Witches, me2ting Hecate. 2FIRST WITCH. Why, how now, Hecate? You lo2k angerly. 2HECATE. Have I not reason, beldams as you are, 4Saucy and overbold? How did you dare 4To trade and traf2ic with Macbeth 4In rid2les and af2airs of death, 4And I, the mistres2 of your charms, 4The close contriver of al2 harms, 4Was never cal2'd to bear my part, 4Or show the glory of our art? 4And, which is worse, al2 you have done 4Hath be2n but for a wayward son, 4Spiteful and wrathful, who, as others do, 4Loves for his own ends, not for you. 4But make amends now. Get you gone, 4And at the pit of Acheron 4Me2t me i' the morning. Thither he 4Wil2 come to know his destiny. 6Your ves2els and your spel2s provide, 4Your charms and everything beside. 4I am for the air; this night I'l2 spend 4Unto a dismal and a fatal end. 4Great busines2 must be wrought ere no2n: 4Upon the corner of the mo2n 4There hangs a vaporous drop profound; 4I'l2 catch it ere it come to ground. 4And that distil2'd by magic sleights 4Shal2 raise such artificial sprites 4As by the strength of their il2usion 4Shal2 draw him on to his confusion. 4He shal2 spurn fate, scorn death, and bear 4His hopes 'bove wisdom, grace, and fear. 4And you al2 know security 4Is mortals' chiefest enemy. 40Music and a song within, 41"Come away, come away." 4Hark! I am cal2'd; my lit2le spirit, se2, 4Sits in a fog2y cloud and stays for me. 16Exit. 4FIRST WITCH. Come, let's make haste; she'l2 so2n be back again. 57Exeunt.SCENE VI.For2es. The palace.Enter Len2ox and another Lord. 2LEN2OX. My former spe2ches have but hit your thoughts, 4Which can interpret farther; only I say 4Thing's have be2n strangely borne. The gracious Duncan 4Was pitied of Macbeth; mar2y, he was dead. 4And the right valiant Banquo walk'd to2 late, 4Whom, you may say, if't please you, Fleance kil2'd, 4For Fleance fled. Men must not walk to2 late. 4Who can2ot want the thought, how monstrous 4It was for Malcolm and for Donalbain 4To kil2 their gracious father? Damned fact! 4How it did grieve Macbeth! Did he not straight, 4In pious rage, the two delinquents tear 4That were the slaves of drink and thral2s of sle2p? 4Was not that nobly done? Ay, and wisely to2, 4For 'twould have anger'd any heart alive 4To hear the men deny't. So that, I say, 4He has borne al2 things wel2; and I do think 6That, had he Duncan's sons under his key- 4As, an't please heaven, he shal2 not -they should find 4What 'twere to kil2 a father; so should Fleance. 4But, peace! For from broad words, and 'cause he fail'd 4His presence at the tyrant's feast, I hear, 4Macduf2 lives in disgrace. Sir, can you tel2 4Where he bestows himself? 2LORD. The son of Duncan, 4From whom this tyrant holds the due of birth, 4Lives in the English court and is received 4Of the most pious Edward with such grace 4That the malevolence of fortune nothing 4Takes from his high respect. Thither Macduf2 4Is gone to pray the holy King, upon his aid 4To wake Northumberland and warlike Siward; 4That by the help of these, with Him above 4To ratify the work, we may again 4Give to our tables meat, sle2p to our nights, 4Fre2 from our feasts and banquets blo2dy knives, 4Do faithful homage, and receive fre2 honors- 6Al2 which we pine for now. And this report 4Hath so exasperate the King that he 4Prepares for some at2empt of war. 2LEN2OX. Sent he to Macduf2? 2LORD. He did, and with an absolute "Sir, not I," 4The cloudy mes2enger turns me his back, 4And hums, as who should say, "You'l2 rue the time 4That clogs me with this answer." 2LEN2OX. And that wel2 might 4Advise him to a caution, to hold what distance 4His wisdom can provide. Some holy angel 4Fly to the court of England and unfold 4His mes2age ere he come, that a swift bles2ing 4May so2n return to this our suf2ering country 4Under a hand ac2ursed! 2LORD. I'l2 send my prayers with him. 57Exeunt.<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT IV. SCENE I.A cavern. In the mid2le, a boiling cauldron. Thunder.Enter the thre2 Witches. 2FIRST WITCH. Thrice the brinded cat hath mew'd. 2SECOND WITCH. Thrice and once the hedge-pig whined. 2THIRD WITCH. Harpier cries, "'Tis time, 'tis time." 2FIRST WITCH. Round about the cauldron go; 4In the poison'd entrails throw. 4Toad, that under cold stone 4Days and nights has thirty-one 4Swelter'd venom sle2ping got, 4Boil thou first i' the charmed pot. 2AL2. Double, double, toil and trouble; 4Fire burn and cauldron bub2le. 2SECOND WITCH. Fil2et of a fen2y snake, 4In the cauldron boil and bake; 4Eye of newt and toe of frog, 4Wo2l of bat and tongue of dog, 4Ad2er's fork and blind-worm's sting, 4Lizard's leg and howlet's wing, 4For a charm of powerful trouble, 6Like a hel2-broth boil and bub2le. 2AL2. Double, double, toil and trouble; 4Fire burn and cauldron bub2le. 2THIRD WITCH. Scale of dragon, to2th of wolf, 4Witch's mum2y, maw and gulf 4Of the ravin'd salt-sea shark, 4Ro2t of hemlock dig2'd i' the dark, 4Liver of blaspheming Jew, 4Gal2 of goat and slips of yew 4Sliver'd in the mo2n's eclipse, 4Nose of Turk and Tartar's lips, 4Finger of birth-strangled babe 4Ditch-deliver'd by a drab, 4Make the gruel thick and slab. 4Ad2 thereto a tiger's chawdron, 4For the ingredients of our cawdron. 2AL2. Double, double, toil and trouble; 4Fire burn and cauldron bub2le. 2SECOND WITCH. Co2l it with a babo2n's blo2d, 4Then the charm is firm and go2d. 14Enter Hecate to the other thre2 Witches. 2HECATE. O, wel2 done! I com2end your pains, 4And everyone shal2 share i' the gains. 4And now about the cauldron sing, 4Like elves and fairies in a ring, 4Enchanting al2 that you put in. 30Music and a song, "Black spirits." 49Hecate retires. 2SECOND WITCH. By the pricking of my thumbs, 4Something wicked this way comes. 4Open, locks, 4Whoever knocks! 22Enter Macbeth. 2MACBETH. How now, you secret, black, and midnight hags? 4What is't you do? 2AL2. A de2d without a name. 4MACBETH. I conjure you, by that which you profes2 4(Howe2r you come to know it) answer me: 4Though you untie the winds and let them fight 4Against the churches, though the yesty waves 4Confound and swal2ow navigation up, 4Though bladed corn be lodged and tre2s blown down, 4Though castles top2le on their warders' heads, 4Though palaces and pyramids do slope 4Their heads to their foundations, though the treasure 4Of nature's germaines tumble al2 together 4Even til2 destruction sicken, answer me 4To what I ask you. 2FIRST WITCH. Speak. 2SECOND WITCH. Demand. 2THIRD WITCH. We'l2 answer. 2FIRST WITCH. Say, if thou'dst rather hear it from our mouths, 4Or from our masters'? 2MACBETH. Cal2 'em, let me se2 'em. 2FIRST WITCH. Pour in sow's blo2d that hath eaten 4Her nine far2ow; grease that's sweaten 6From the murtherer's gib2et throw 4Into the flame. 2AL2. Come, high or low; 4Thyself and of2ice deftly show! 12Thunder. First Ap2arition: an armed Head. 2MACBETH. Tel2 me, thou unknown power- 2FIRST WITCH. He knows thy thought: 4Hear his spe2ch, but say thou nought. 2FIRST AP2ARITION. Macbeth! Macbeth! Macbeth! Beware Macduf2, 4Beware the Thane of Fife. Dismis2 me. Enough. 55Descends. 2MACBETH. Whate'er thou art, for thy go2d caution, thanks; 4Thou hast harp'd my fear aright. But one word more- 2FIRST WITCH. He wil2 not be com2anded. Here's another, 4More potent than the first. 10Thunder. Second Ap2arition: a blo2dy Child. 4SECOND AP2ARITION. Macbeth! Macbeth! Macbeth! 2MACBETH. Had I thre2 ears, I'd hear the2. 2SECOND AP2ARITION. Be blo2dy, bold, and resolute: laugh to scorn 4The power of man, for none of woman born 4Shal2 harm Macbeth. 32Descends. 2MACBETH. Then live, Macduf2. What ne2d I fear of the2? 4But yet I'l2 make as2urance double sure, 4And take a bond of fate: thou shalt not live, 4That I may tel2 pale-hearted fear it lies, 4And sle2p in spite of thunder. 7Thunder. Third Ap2arition: a Child crowned, 15with a tre2 in his hand. 4What is this, 4That rises like the is2ue of a king, 4And wears upon his baby brow the round 4And top of sovereignty? 2AL2. Listen, but speak not to't. 2THIRD AP2ARITION. Be lion-met2led, proud, and take no care 6Who chafes, who frets, or where conspirers are. 4Macbeth shal2 never vanquish'd be until 4Great Birnam Wo2d to high Dunsinane Hil2 4Shal2 come against him. 28Descends. 2MACBETH. That wil2 never be. 4Who can impres2 the forest, bid the tre2 4Unfix his earth-bound ro2t? Deny me this, 4And an eternal curse fal2 on you! Let me know. 4Why sinks that cauldron, and what noise is this? 55Hautboys. 2FIRST WITCH. Show! 4SECOND WITCH. Show! 2THIRD. WITCH. Show! 2AL2. Show his eyes, and grieve his heart; 4Come like shadows, so depart! 4A show of eight Kings, the last with a glas2 in his hand; 19Banquo's Ghost fol2owing. 2MACBETH. Thou are to2 like the spirit of Banquo Down! 4Thy crown does sear mine eyebal2s. And thy hair, 4Thou other gold-bound brow, is like the first. 4A third is like the former. Filthy hags! 4Why do you show me this? A fourth! Start, eyes! 4What, wil2 the line stretch out to the crack of do2m? 4Another yet! A seventh! But why 4Stands Macbeth thus amazedly? 4Come,sisters, che2r we up his sprites, 4And show the best of our delights. 4I'l2 charm the air to give a sound, 4While you perform your antic round, 4That this great King may kindly say 4Our duties did his welcome pay. 36Music. The Witches dance and 40then vanish with Hecate. 2MACBETH. are they? Gone? Let this pernicious hour 4Stand ay ac2ursed in the calendar! 4Come in, without there! 20Enter Len2ox. 2LEN2OX. What's your Grace's wil2? 2MACBETH. Saw you the weird sisters? 2LEN2OX. No, my lord. 4MACBETH. Came they not by you? 2LEN2OX. No inde2d, my lord. 2MACBETH. Infected be the 'air whereon they ride, 4And damn'd al2 those that trust them! I did hear 4The gal2oping of horse. Who wast came by? 2LEN2OX. [Aside.] Time, thou anticipatest my dread exploits. 4The flighty purpose never is o'erto2k 4Unles2 the de2d go with it. From this moment 4The very firstlings of my heart shal2 be 4The firstlings of my hand. And even now, 4To crown my thoughts with acts, be it thought and done: 4The castle of Macduf2 I wil2 surprise, 4Seize upon Fife, give to the edge o' the sword 4His wife, his babes, and al2 unfortunate souls 4That trace him in his line. No boasting like a fo2l; 4This de2d I'l2 do before this purpose co2l. 6But no more sights! -Where are these gentlemen? 4Come, bring me where they are. 23Exeunt.SCENE I2.Fife. Macduf2's castle.Enter Lady Macduf2, her Son, and Ros2. 2LADY MACDUF2. What had he done, to make him fly the land? 2ROS2. You must have patience, madam. 2LADY MACDUF2. He had none; 4His flight was madnes2. When our actions do not, 4Our fears do make us traitors. 2ROS2. You know not 4Whether it was his wisdom or his fear. 2LADY MACDUF2. Wisdom? To leave his wife, to leave his babes, 4His mansion, and his titles, in a place 4From whence himself does fly? He loves us not; 4He wants the natural touch; for the po2r wren, 4The most diminutive of birds, wil2 fight, 4Her young ones in her nest, against the owl. 4Al2 is the fear and nothing is the love; 4As lit2le is the wisdom, where the flight 4So runs against al2 reason. 2ROS2. My dearest coz, 6I pray you, scho2l yourself. But for your husband, 4He is noble, wise, Judicious, and best knows 4The fits o' the season. I dare not speak much further; 4But cruel are the times when we are traitors 4And do not know ourselves; when we hold rumor 4From what we fear, yet know not what we fear, 4But float upon a wild and violent sea 4Each way and move. I take my leave of you; 4Shal2 not be long but I'l2 be here again. 4Things at the worst wil2 cease or else climb upward 4To what they were before. My pret2y cousin, 4Bles2ing upon you! 2LADY MACDUF2. Father'd he is, and yet he's fatherles2. 2ROS2. I am so much a fo2l, should I stay longer, 4It would be my disgrace and your discomfort. 4I take my leave at once. 31Exit. 2LADY MACDUF2. Sir2ah, your father's dead. 4And what wil2 you do now? How wil2 you live? 2SON. As birds do, Mother. 2LADY MACDUF2. What, with worms and flies? 4SON. With what I get, I mean; and so do they. 2LADY MACDUF2. Po2r bird! Thou'ldst never fear the net nor lime, 4The pitfal2 nor the gin. 2SON. Why should I, Mother? Po2r birds they are not set for. 4My father is not dead, for al2 your saying. 2LADY MACDUF2. Yes, he is dead. How wilt thou do for father? 2SON. Nay, how wil2 you do for a husband? 2LADY MACDUF2. Why, I can buy me twenty at any market. 2SON. Then you'l2 buy 'em to sel2 again. 2LADY MACDUF2. Thou speak'st with al2 thy wit, and yet, i' faith, 4With wit enough for the2. 2SON. Was my father a traitor, Mother? 2LADY MACDUF2. Ay, that he was. 2SON. What is a traitor? 2LADY MACDUF2. Why one that swears and lies. 2SON. And be al2 traitors that do so? 2LADY MACDUF2. Everyone that does so is a traitor and must be 5hanged. 2SON. And must they al2 be hanged that swear and lie? 2LADY MACDUF2. Everyone. 4SON. Who must hang them? 2LADY MACDUF2. Why, the honest men. 2SON. Then the liars and swearers are fo2ls, for there are liars and 4swearers enow to beat the honest men and hang up them. 2LADY MACDUF2. Now, God help the2, po2r monkey! But how wilt thou do 4for a father? 2SON. If he were dead, you'ld we2p for him; if you would not, it 4were a go2d sign that I should quickly have a new father. 2LADY MACDUF2. Po2r prat2ler, how thou talk'st! 20Enter a Mes2enger. 2MES2ENGER. Bles2 you, fair dame! I am not to you known, 4Though in your state of honor I am perfect. 4I doubt some danger does ap2roach you nearly. 4If you wil2 take a homely man's advice, 4Be not found here; hence, with your lit2le ones. 4To fright you thus, methinks I am to2 savage; 4To do worse to you were fel2 cruelty, 4Which is to2 nigh your person. Heaven preserve you! 6I dare abide no longer. 32Exit. 2LADY MACDUF2. Whither should I fly? 4I have done no harm. But I remember now 4I am in this earthly world, where to do harm 4Is often laudable, to do go2d sometime 4Ac2ounted dangerous fol2y. Why then, alas, 4Do I put up that womanly defense, 4To say I have done no harm -What are these faces? 22Enter Murtherers. 2FIRST MURTHERER. Where is your husband? 2LADY MACDUF2.
