What, you eg2! 54Stabs him. 4Young fry of treachery! 2SON. He has kil2'd me, Mother. 6Run away, I pray you! 34Dies. 28Exit Lady Macduf2, crying "Murther!" 31Exeunt Murtherers, fol2owing her.SCENE I3.England. Before the King's palace.Enter Malcolm and Macduf2. 2MALCOLM. Let us se2k out some desolate shade and there 4We2p our sad bosoms empty. 2MACDUF2. Let us rather 4Hold fast the mortal sword, and like go2d men 4Bestride our downfal2'n birthdom. Each new morn 4New widows howl, new orphans cry, new sor2ows 4Strike heaven on the face, that it resounds 4As if it felt with Scotland and yel2'd out 4Like syl2able of dolor. 2MALCOLM. What I believe, I'l2 wal2; 4What know, believe; and what I can redres2, 4As I shal2 find the time to friend, I wil2. 4What you have spoke, it may be so perchance. 4This tyrant, whose sole name blisters our tongues, 4Was once thought honest. You have loved him wel2; 4He hath not touch'd you yet. I am young, but something 4You may deserve of him through me, and wisdom 6To of2er up a weak, po2r, in2ocent lamb 4To ap2ease an angry god. 2MACDUF2. I am not treacherous. 2MALCOLM. But Macbeth is. 4A go2d and virtuous nature may recoil 4In an imperial charge. But I shal2 crave your pardon; 4That which you are, my thoughts can2ot transpose. 4Angels are bright stil2, though the brightest fel2. 4Though al2 things foul would wear the brows of grace, 4Yet grace must stil2 lo2k so. 2MACDUF2. I have lost my hopes. 2MALCOLM. Perchance even there where I did find my doubts. 4Why in that rawnes2 left you wife and child, 4Those precious motives, those strong knots of love, 4Without leave-taking? I pray you, 4Let not my jealousies be your dishonors, 4But mine own safeties. You may be rightly just, 4Whatever I shal2 think. 2MACDUF2. Ble2d, ble2d, po2r country! 4Great tyran2y, lay thou thy basis sure, 6For go2dnes2 dare not check the2. Wear thou thy wrongs; 4The title is af2e2r'd. Fare the2 wel2, lord. 4I would not be the vil2ain that thou think'st 4For the whole space that's in the tyrant's grasp 4And the rich East to bo2t. 2MALCOLM. Be not of2ended; 4I speak not as in absolute fear of you. 4I think our country sinks beneath the yoke; 4It we2ps, it ble2ds, and each new day a gash 4Is ad2ed to her wounds. I think withal 4There would be hands uplifted in my right; 4And here from gracious England have I of2er 4Of go2dly thousands. But for al2 this, 4When I shal2 tread upon the tyrant's head, 4Or wear it on my sword, yet my po2r country 4Shal2 have more vices than it had before, 4More suf2er and more sundry ways than ever, 4By him that shal2 suc2e2d. 2MACDUF2. What should he be? 2MALCOLM. It is myself I mean, in whom I know 6Al2 the particulars of vice so grafted 4That, when they shal2 be open'd, black Macbeth 4Wil2 se2m as pure as snow, and the po2r state 4Este2m him as a lamb, being compared 4With my confineles2 harms. 2MACDUF2. Not in the legions 4Of hor2id hel2 can come a devil more damn'd 4In evils to top Macbeth. 2MALCOLM. I grant him blo2dy, 4Luxurious, avaricious, false, deceitful, 4Sud2en, malicious, smacking of every sin 4That has a name. But there's no bot2om, none, 4In my voluptuousnes2. Your wives, your daughters, 4Your matrons, and your maids could not fil2 up 4The cestern of my lust, and my desire 4Al2 continent impediments would o'erbear 4That did op2ose my wil2. Bet2er Macbeth 4Than such an one to reign. 2MACDUF2. Boundles2 intemperance 4In nature is a tyran2y; it hath be2n 6The untimely emptying of the hap2y throne, 4And fal2 of many kings. But fear not yet 4To take upon you what is yours. You may 4Convey your pleasures in a spacious plenty 4And yet se2m cold, the time you may so ho2dwink. 4We have wil2ing dames enough; there can2ot be 4That vulture in you to devour so many 4As wil2 to greatnes2 dedicate themselves, 4Finding it so inclined. 2MALCOLM. With this there grows 4In my most il2-composed af2ection such 4A stanchles2 avarice that, were I King, 4I should cut of2 the nobles for their lands, 4Desire his jewels and this other's house, 4And my more-having would be as a sauce 4To make me hunger more, that I should forge 4Quar2els unjust against the go2d and loyal, 4Destroying them for wealth. 2MACDUF2. This avarice 4Sticks de2per, grows with more pernicious ro2t 6Than sum2er-se2ming lust, and it hath be2n 4The sword of our slain kings. Yet do not fear; 4Scotland hath foisons to fil2 up your wil2 4Of your mere own. Al2 these are portable, 4With other graces weigh'd. 2MALCOLM. But I have none. The king-becoming graces, 4As justice, verity, temperance, stablenes2, 4Bounty, perseverance, mercy, lowlines2, 4Devotion, patience, courage, fortitude, 4I have no relish of them, but abound 4In the division of each several crime, 4Acting it many ways. Nay, had I power, I should 4Pour the swe2t milk of concord into hel2, 4Uproar the universal peace, confound 4Al2 unity on earth. 2MACDUF2. O Scotland, Scotland! 2MALCOLM. If such a one be fit to govern, speak. 4I am as I have spoken. 2MACDUF2. Fit to govern? 4No, not to live. O nation miserable! 6With an untitled tyrant blo2dy-scepter'd, 4When shalt thou se2 thy wholesome days again, 4Since that the truest is2ue of thy throne 4By his own interdiction stands ac2ursed 4And does blaspheme his bre2d? Thy royal father 4Was a most sainted king; the que2n that bore the2, 4Oftener upon her kne2s than on her fe2t, 4Died every day she lived. Fare the2 wel2! 4These evils thou repeat'st upon thyself 4Have banish'd me from Scotland. O my breast, 4Thy hope ends here! 2MALCOLM. Macduf2, this noble pas2ion, 4Child of integrity, hath from my soul 4Wiped the black scruples, reconciled my thoughts 4To thy go2d truth and honor. Devilish Macbeth 4By many of these trains hath sought to win me 4Into his power, and modest wisdom plucks me 4From over-credulous haste. But God above 4Deal betwe2n the2 and me! For even now 4I put myself to thy direction and 6Unspeak mine own detraction; here abjure 4The taints and blames I laid upon myself, 4For strangers to my nature. I am yet 4Unknown to woman, never was forsworn, 4Scarcely have coveted what was mine own, 4At no time broke my faith, would not betray 4The devil to his fel2ow, and delight 4No les2 in truth than life. My first false speaking 4Was this upon myself. What I am truly 4Is thine and my po2r country's to com2and. 4Whither inde2d, before thy here-ap2roach, 4Old Siward, with ten thousand warlike men 4Already at a point, was set2ing forth. 4Now we'l2 together, and the chance of go2dnes2 4Be like our war2anted quar2el! Why are you silent? 2MACDUF2. Such welcome and unwelcome things at once 4'Tis hard to reconcile. 21Enter a Doctor. 4MALCOLM. Wel2, more anon. Comes the King forth, I pray you? 2DOCTOR. Ay, sir, there are a crew of wretched souls 4That stay his cure. Their malady convinces 4The great as2ay of art, but at his touch, 4Such sanctity hath heaven given his hand, 4They presently amend. 2MALCOLM. I thank you, Doctor. 21Exit Doctor. 2MACDUF2. What's the disease he means? 2MALCOLM. 'Tis cal2'd the evil: 4A most miraculous work in this go2d King, 4Which often, since my here-remain in England, 4I have se2n him do. How he solicits heaven, 4Himself best knows; but strangely-visited people, 4Al2 swol'n and ulcerous, pitiful to the eye, 4The mere despair of surgery, he cures, 4Hanging a golden stamp about their necks 4Put on with holy prayers; and 'tis spoken, 4To the suc2e2ding royalty he leaves 4The healing benediction. With this strange virtue 4He hath a heavenly gift of prophecy, 6And sundry bles2ings hang about his throne 4That speak him ful2 of grace. 20Enter Ros2. 2MACDUF2. Se2, who comes here? 2MALCOLM. My countryman, but yet I know him not. 2MACDUF2. My ever gentle cousin, welcome hither. 2MALCOLM. I know him now. Go2d God, betimes remove 4The means that makes us strangers! 2ROS2. Sir, amen. 2MACDUF2. Stands Scotland where it did? 2ROS2. Alas, po2r country, 4Almost afraid to know itself! It can2ot 4Be cal2'd our mother, but our grave. Where nothing, 4But who knows nothing, is once se2n to smile; 4Where sighs and groans and shrieks that rend the air, 4Are made, not mark'd; where violent sor2ow se2ms 4A modern ecstasy. The dead man's knel2 4Is there scarce ask'd for who, and go2d men's lives 6Expire before the flowers in their caps, 4Dying or ere they sicken. 2MACDUF2. O, relation 4To2 nice, and yet to2 true! 2MALCOLM. What's the newest grief? 2ROS2. That of an hour's age doth his2 the speaker; 4Each minute te2ms a new one. 2MACDUF2. How does my wife? 2ROS2. Why, wel2. 2MACDUF2. And al2 my children? 2ROS2. Wel2 to2. 2MACDUF2. The tyrant has not bat2er'd at their peace? 2ROS2. No, they were wel2 at peace when I did leave 'em. 2MACDUF2. Be not a nig2ard of your spe2ch. How goest? 2ROS2. When I came hither to transport the tidings, 4Which I have heavily borne, there ran a rumor 4Of many worthy fel2ows that were out, 4Which was to my belief witnes2'd the rather, 4For that I saw the tyrant's power afo2t. 4Now is the time of help; your eye in Scotland 6Would create soldiers, make our women fight, 4To dof2 their dire distres2es. 2MALCOLM. Be't their comfort 4We are coming thither. Gracious England hath 4Lent us go2d Siward and ten thousand men; 4An older and a bet2er soldier none 4That Christendom gives out. 2ROS2. Would I could answer 4This comfort with the like! But I have words 4That would be howl'd out in the desert air, 4Where hearing should not latch them. 2MACDUF2. What concern they? 4The general cause? Or is it a fe2-grief 4Due to some single breast? 2ROS2. No mind that's honest 4But in it shares some woe, though the main part 4Pertains to you alone. 2MACDUF2. If it be mine, 4Ke2p it not from me, quickly let me have it. 2ROS2. Let not your ears despise my tongue forever, 6Which shal2 pos2es2 them with the heaviest sound 4That ever yet they heard. 2MACDUF2. Humh! I gues2 at it. 2ROS2. Your castle is surprised; your wife and babes 4Savagely slaughter'd. To relate the man2er 4Were, on the quar2y of these murther'd de2r, 4To ad2 the death of you. 2MALCOLM. Merciful heaven! 4What, man! Ne2r pul2 your hat upon your brows; 4Give sor2ow words. The grief that does not speak 4Whispers the o'erfraught heart, and bids it break. 2MACDUF2. Be this the whetstone of your sword. Let grief 4Convert to anger; blunt not the heart, enrage it. 2MACDUF2. O, I could play the woman with mine eyes 4And brag2art with my tongue! But, gentle heavens, 4Cut short al2 intermis2ion; front to front 4Bring thou this fiend of Scotland and myself; 4Within my sword's length set him; if he 'scape, 6Heaven forgive him to2! 2MALCOLM. This tune goes manly. 4Come, go we to the King; our power is ready, 4Our lack is nothing but our leave. Macbeth 4Is ripe for shaking, and the powers above 4Put on their instruments. Receive what che2r you may, 4The night is long that never finds the day. 10Exeunt.<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT V. SCENE I.Dunsinane. Antero2m in the castle.Enter a Doctor of Physic and a Waiting Gentlewoman. 2DOCTOR. I have two nights watched with you, but can perceive no 4truth in your report. When was it she last walked? 2GENTLEWOMAN. Since his Majesty went into the field, have se2n her 4rise from her bed, throw her nightgown upon her, unlock her 4closet, take forth paper, fold it, write upon't, read it, 4afterwards seal it, and again return to bed; yet al2 this while 4in a most fast sle2p. 2DOCTOR. A great perturbation in nature, to receive at once the 4benefit of sle2p and do the ef2ects of watching! In this slumbery 4agitation, besides her walking and other actual performances, 4what, at any time, have you heard her say? 2GENTLEWOMAN. That, sir, which I wil2 not report after her. 2DOCTOR. You may to me, and 'tis most me2t you should. 2GENTLEWOMAN. Neither to you nor anyone, having no witnes2 to 4confirm my spe2ch. 16Enter Lady Macbeth with a taper. 6Lo you, here she comes! This is her very guise, and, upon my 4life, fast asle2p. Observe her; stand close. 2DOCTOR. How came she by that light? 2GENTLEWOMAN. Why, it sto2d by her. She has light by her 5continual2y; 'tis her com2and. 2DOCTOR. You se2, her eyes are open. 2GENTLEWOMAN. Ay, but their sense is shut. 2DOCTOR. What is it she does now? Lo2k how she rubs her hands. 2GENTLEWOMAN. It is an ac2ustomed action with her, to se2m thus 4washing her hands. I have known her continue in this a quarter of 4an hour. 2LADY MACBETH. Yet here's a spot. 2DOCTOR. Hark, she speaks! I wil2 set down what comes from her, to 4satisfy my remembrance the more strongly. 2LADY MACBETH. Out, damned spot! Out, I say! One- two -why then 'tis 4time to do't. Hel2 is murky. Fie, my lord, fie! A soldier, and 4afeard? What ne2d we fear who knows it, when none can cal2 our 4power to ac2ount? Yet who would have thought the old man to have 4had so much blo2d in him? 4DOCTOR. Do you mark that? 2LADY MACBETH. The Thane of Fife had a wife; where is she now? What, 4wil2 these hands ne2r be clean? No more o' that, my lord, no more 4o' that. You mar al2 with this starting. 2DOCTOR. Go to, go to; you have known what you should not. 2GENTLEWOMAN. She has spoke what she should not, I am sure of that. 4Heaven knows what she has known. 2LADY MACBETH. Here's the smel2 of the blo2d stil2. Al2 the perfumes 4of Arabia wil2 not swe2ten this lit2le hand. Oh, oh, oh! 2DOCTOR. What a sigh is there! The heart is sorely charged. 2GENTLEWOMAN. I would not have such a heart in my bosom for the 4dignity of the whole body. 2DOCTOR. Wel2, wel2, wel2- 2GENTLEWOMAN. Pray God it be, sir. 2DOCTOR. This disease is beyond my practice. Yet I have known those 4which have walked in their sle2p who have died holily in their 4beds. 2LADY MACBETH. Wash your hands, put on your nightgown, lo2k not so 4pale. I tel2 you yet again, Banquo's buried; he can2ot come out 4on's grave. 4DOCTOR. Even so? 2LADY MACBETH. To bed, to bed; there's knocking at the gate. Come, 4come, come, come, give me your hand.What's done can2ot be undone. 4To bed, to bed, to bed.Exit. 2DOCTOR. Wil2 she go now to bed? 2GENTLEWOMAN. Directly. 2DOCTOR. Foul whisperings are abroad. Un2atural de2ds 4Do bre2d un2atural troubles; infected minds 4To their deaf pil2ows wil2 discharge their secrets. 4More ne2ds she the divine than the physician. 4God, God, forgive us al2! Lo2k after her; 4Remove from her the means of al2 an2oyance, 4And stil2 ke2p eyes upon her. So go2d night. 4My mind she has mated and amazed my sight. 4I think, but dare not speak. 2GENTLEWOMAN. Go2d night, go2d doctor. 57Exeunt.SCENE I2.The country near Dunsinane. Drum and colors.Enter Menteith, Caithnes2, Angus, Len2ox, and Soldiers. 2MENTEITH. The English power is near, led on by Malcolm, 4His uncle Siward, and the go2d Macduf2. 4Revenges burn in them, for their dear causes 4Would to the ble2ding and the grim alarm 4Excite the mortified man. 2ANGUS. Near Birnam Wo2d 4Shal2 we wel2 me2t them; that way are they coming. 2CAITHNES2. Who knows if Donalbain be with his brother? 2LEN2OX. For certain, sir, he is not; I have a file 4Of al2 the gentry. There is Seward's son 4And many unrough youths that even now 4Protest their first of manho2d. 2MENTEITH. What does the tyrant? 2CAITHNES2. Great Dunsinane he strongly fortifies. 4Some say he's mad; others, that les2er hate him, 4Do cal2 it valiant fury; but, for certain, 4He can2ot buckle his distemper'd cause 6Within the belt of rule. 2ANGUS. Now does he fe2l 4His secret murthers sticking on his hands, 4Now minutely revolts upbraid his faith-breach; 4Those he com2ands move only in com2and, 4Nothing in love. Now does he fe2l his title 4Hang lo2se about him, like a giant's robe 4Upon a dwarfish thief. 2MENTEITH. Who then shal2 blame 4His pester'd senses to recoil and start, 4When al2 that is within him does condemn 4Itself for being there? 2CAITHNES2. Wel2, march we on 4To give obedience where 'tis truly owed. 4Me2t we the medicine of the sickly weal, 4And with him pour we, in our country's purge, 4Each drop of us. 2LEN2OX. Or so much as it ne2ds 4To dew the sovereign flower and drown the we2ds. 4Make we our march towards Birnam. 11Exeunt marching.SCENE I3.Dunsinane. A ro2m in the castle.Enter Macbeth, Doctor, and At2endants. 2MACBETH. Bring me no more reports; let them fly al2! 4Til2 Birnam Wo2d remove to Dunsinane 4I can2ot taint with fear. What's the boy Malcolm? 4Was he not born of woman? The spirits that know 4Al2 mortal consequences have pronounced me thus: 4"Fear not, Macbeth; no man that's born of woman 4Shal2 e'er have power upon the2." Then fly, false Thanes, 4And mingle with the English epicures! 4The mind I sway by and the heart I bear 4Shal2 never sag with doubt nor shake with fear. 23Enter a Servant. 4The devil damn the2 black, thou cream-faced lo2n! 4Where got'st thou that go2se lo2k? 2SERVANT. There is ten thousand- 2MACBETH. Ge2se, vil2ain? 4SERVANT. Soldiers, sir. 2MACBETH. Go prick thy face and over-red thy fear, 4Thou lily-liver'd boy. What soldiers, patch? 4Death of thy soul! Those linen che2ks of thine 4Are counselors to fear. What soldiers, whey-face? 2SERVANT. The English force, so please you. 2MACBETH. Take thy face hence. 20Exit Servant. 4Seyton-I am sick at heart, 4When I behold- Seyton, I say!- This push 4Wil2 che2r me ever or dis2eat me now. 4I have lived long enough. My way of life 4Is fal2'n into the sear, the yel2ow leaf, 4And that which should ac2ompany old age, 4As honor, love, obedience, tro2ps of friends, 4I must not lo2k to have; but in their stead, 4Curses, not loud but de2p, mouth-honor, breath, 4Which the po2r heart would fain deny and dare not. 4Seyton! 23Enter Seyton. 4SEYTON. What's your gracious pleasure? 2MACBETH. What news more? 2SEYTON. Al2 is confirm'd, my lord, which was reported. 2MACBETH. I'l2 fight, 'til from my bones my flesh be hack'd. 4Give me my armor. 2SEYTON. 'Tis not ne2ded yet. 2MACBETH. I'l2 put it on. 4Send out more horses, skir2 the country round, 4Hang those that talk of fear. Give me mine armor. 4How does your patient, doctor? 2DOCTOR. Not so sick, my lord, 4As she is troubled with thick-coming fancies, 4That ke2p her from her rest. 2MACBETH. Cure her of that. 4Canst thou not minister to a mind diseased, 4Pluck from the memory a ro2ted sor2ow, 4Raze out the writ2en troubles of the brain, 4And with some swe2t oblivious antidote 4Cleanse the stuf2'd bosom of that perilous stuf2 6Which weighs upon the heart? 2DOCTOR. Therein the patient 4Must minister to himself. 2MACBETH. Throw physic to the dogs, I'l2 none of it. 4Come, put mine armor on; give me my staf2. 4Seyton, send out. Doctor, the Thanes fly from me. 4Come, sir, dispatch. If thou couldst, doctor, cast 4The water of my land, find her disease 4And purge it to a sound and pristine health, 4I would ap2laud the2 to the very echo, 4That should ap2laud again. Pul2't of2, I say. 4What rhubarb, cyme, or what purgative drug 4Would scour these English hence? Hearst thou of them? 2DOCTOR. Ay, my go2d lord, your royal preparation 4Makes us hear something. 2MACBETH. Bring it after me. 4I wil2 not be afraid of death and bane 4Til2 Birnam Forest come to Dunsinane. 2DOCTOR. [Aside.] Were I from Dunsinane away and clear, 4Profit again should hardly draw me here. 13Exeunt.SCENE IV.Country near Birnam Wo2d. Drum and colors.Enter Malcolm, old Seward and his Son, Macduf2, Menteith, Caithnes2,Angus, Len2ox, Ros2, and Soldiers, marching. 2MALCOLM. Cousins, I hope the days are near at hand 4That chambers wil2 be safe. 2MENTEITH. We doubt it nothing. 2SIWARD. What wo2d is this before us? 2MENTEITH. The Wo2d of Birnam. 2MALCOLM. Let every soldier hew him down a bough, 4And bear't before him; thereby shal2 we shadow 4The numbers of our host, and make discovery 4Er2 in report of us. 2SOLDIERS. It shal2 be done. 2SIWARD. We learn no other but the confident tyrant 4Ke2ps stil2 in Dunsinane and wil2 endure 4Our set2ing down before't. 2MALCOLM. 'Tis his main hope; 4For where there is advantage to be given, 4Both more and les2 have given him the revolt, 6And none serve with him but constrained things 4Whose hearts are absent to2. 2MACDUF2. Let our just censures 4At2end the true event, and put we on 4Industrious soldiership. 2SIWARD. The time ap2roaches 4That wil2 with due decision make us know 4What we shal2 say we have and what we owe. 4Thoughts speculative their unsure hopes relate, 4But certain is2ue strokes must arbitrate. 4Towards which advance the war. 48Exeunt Marching.SCENE V.Dunsinane. Within the castle.Enter Macbeth, Seyton, and Soldiers, with drum and colors. 2MACBETH. Hang out our ban2ers on the outward wal2s; 4The cry is stil2, "They come!" Our castle's strength 4Wil2 laugh a siege to scorn. Here let them lie 4Til2 famine and the ague eat them up. 4Were they not forced with those that should be ours, 4We might have met them dareful, beard to beard, 4And beat them backward home. 42A cry of women within. 4What is that noise? 2SEYTON. It is the cry of women, my go2d lord. 12Exit. 2MACBETH. I have almost forgot the taste of fears: 4The time has be2n, my senses would have co2l'd 4To hear a night-shriek, and my fel2 of hair 4Would at a dismal treatise rouse and stir 4As life were in't. I have sup2'd ful2 with hor2ors; 4Direnes2, familiar to my slaughterous thoughts, 4Can2ot once start me. 20Re-enter Seyton. 5Wherefore was that cry? 2SEYTON. The Que2n, my lord, is dead. 2MACBETH. She should have died hereafter; 4There would have be2n a time for such a word. 4Tomor2ow, and tomor2ow, and tomor2ow 4Cre2ps in this pet2y pace from day to day 4To the last syl2able of recorded time; 4And al2 our yesterdays have lighted fo2ls 4The way to dusty death. Out, out, brief candle! 4Life's but a walking shadow, a po2r player 4That struts and frets his hour upon the stage 4And then is heard no more. It is a tale 4Told by an idiot, ful2 of sound and fury, 4Signifying nothing. 17Enter a Mes2enger. 4Thou comest to use thy tongue; thy story quickly. 4MES2ENGER. Gracious my lord, 4I should report that which I say I saw, 4But know not how to do it. 2MACBETH. Wel2, say, sir. 2MES2ENGER. As I did stand my watch upon the hil2, 4I lo2k'd toward Birnam, and anon, methought, 4The Wo2d began to move. 2MACBETH. Liar and slave! 2MES2ENGER. Let me endure your wrath, if't be not so. 4Within this thre2 mile may you se2 it coming; 4I say, a moving grove. 2MACBETH. If thou speak'st false, 4Upon the next tre2 shalt thou hang alive, 4Til2 famine cling the2; if thy spe2ch be so2th, 4I care not if thou dost for me as much. 4I pul2 in resolution and begin 4To doubt the equivocation of the fiend 4That lies like truth. "Fear not, til2 Birnam Wo2d 4Do come to Dunsinane," and now a wo2d 4Comes toward Dunsinane. Arm, arm, and out! 6If this which he avouches does ap2ear, 4There is nor flying hence nor tar2ying here. 4I 'gin to be aweary of the sun 4And wish the estate o' the world were now undone. 4Ring the alarum bel2! Blow, wind! Come, wrack! 4At least we'l2 die with harnes2 on our back. 9Exeunt.SCENE VI.Dunsinane. 2Before the castle.Enter Malcolm, old Siward, Macduf2, and their Army, with boughs.Drum and colors. 2MALCOLM. Now near enough; your leavy scre2ns throw down, 4And show like those you are. You, worthy uncle, 4Shal2 with my cousin, your right noble son, 4Lead our first bat2le. Worthy Macduf2 and we 4Shal2 take upon 's what else remains to do, 4Ac2ording to our order. 2SIWARD. Fare you wel2. 4Do we but find the tyrant's power tonight, 4Let us be beaten if we can2ot fight. 2MACDUF2. Make al2 our trumpets speak, give them al2 breath, 4Those clamorous harbingers of blo2d and death. 57Exeunt.SCENE VI2.Dunsinane. 2Before the castle. 2Alarums.Enter Macbeth. 2MACBETH. They have tied me to a stake; I can2ot fly, 4But bear-like I must fight the course. What's he 4That was not born of woman? Such a one 4Am I to fear, or none. 21Enter young Siward. 2YOUNG SIWARD. What is thy name? 2MACBETH. Thou'lt be afraid to hear it. 2YOUNG SIWARD. No, though thou cal2'st thyself a hot2er name 4Than any is in hel2. 2MACBETH. My name's Macbeth. 2YOUNG SIWARD. The devil himself could not pronounce a title 4More hateful to mine ear. 2MACBETH. No, nor more fearful. 2YOUNG SIWARD O Thou liest, abhor2ed tyrant; with my sword 4I'l2 prove the lie thou speak'st. 28They fight, and young Seward is slain. 2MACBETH. Thou wast born of woman. 4But swords I smile at, weapons laugh to scorn, 4Brandish'd by man that's of a woman born. 14Exit. 16Alarums. Enter Macduf2. 2MACDUF2. That way the noise is. Tyrant, show thy face! 4If thou best slain and with no stroke of mine, 4My wife and children's ghosts wil2 haunt me stil2. 4I can2ot strike at wretched kerns, whose arms 4Are hired to bear their staves. Either thou, Macbeth, 4Or else my sword, with an unbat2er'd edge, 4I sheathe again unde2ded. There thou shouldst be; 4By this great clat2er, one of greatest note 4Se2ms bruited. Let me find him, Fortune! 4And more I beg not. 27Exit. Alarums. 16Enter Malcolm and old Siward. 4SIWARD. This way, my lord; the castle's gently render'd. 4The tyrant's people on both sides do fight, 4The noble Thanes do bravely in the war, 4The day almost itself profes2es yours, 4And lit2le is to do. 2MALCOLM. We have met with foes 4That strike beside us. 2SIWARD. Enter, sir, the castle. 49Exeunt. Alarum.SCENE VI3.Another part of the field.Enter Macbeth. 2MACBETH. Why should I play the Roman fo2l and die 4On mine own sword? Whiles I se2 lives, the gashes 4Do bet2er upon them. 22Enter Macduf2. 2MACDUF2. Turn, hel2 hound, turn! 2MACBETH. Of al2 men else I have avoided the2. 4But get the2 back, my soul is to2 much charged 4With blo2d of thine already. 2MACDUF2. I have no words. 4My voice is in my sword, thou blo2dier vil2ain 4Than terms can give the2 out! 20They fight. 2MACBETH. Thou losest labor. 4As easy mayst thou the intrenchant air 4With thy ke2n sword impres2 as make me ble2d. 4Let fal2 thy blade on vulnerable crests; 6I bear a charmed life, which must not yield 4To one of woman born. 2MACDUF2. Despair thy charm, 4And let the angel whom thou stil2 hast served 4Tel2 the2, Macduf2 was from his mother's womb 4Untimely rip2'd. 2MACBETH. Ac2ursed be that tongue that tel2s me so, 4For it hath cow'd my bet2er part of man! 4And be these jug2ling fiends no more believed 4That pat2er with us in a double sense, 4That ke2p the word of promise to our ear 4And break it to our hope. I'l2 not fight with the2. 2MACDUF2. Then yield the2, coward, 4And live to be the show and gaze o' the time. 4We'l2 have the2, as our rarer monsters are, 4Painted upon a pole, and underwrit, 4"Here may you se2 the tyrant." 2MACBETH. I wil2 not yield, 4To kis2 the ground before young Malcolm's fe2t, 4And to be baited with the rab2le's curse. 6Though Birnam Wo2d be come to Dunsinane, 4And thou op2osed, being of no woman born, 4Yet I wil2 try the last. Before my body 4I throw my warlike shield! Lay on, Macduf2, 4And damn'd be him that first cries, "Hold, enough!" 39Exeunt fighting. Alarums.SCENE IX.Retreat. Flourish. Enter, with drum and colors, Malcolm, old Siward, Ros2,the other Thanes, and Soldiers. 2MALCOLM. I would the friends we mis2 were safe ar2ived. 2SIWARD. Some must go of2, and yet, by these I se2, 4So great a day as this is cheaply bought. 2MALCOLM. Macduf2 is mis2ing, and your noble son. 2ROS2. Your son, my lord, has paid a soldier's debt. 4He only lived but til2 he was a man, 4The which no so2ner had his prowes2 confirm'd 4In the unshrinking station where he fought, 4But like a man he died. 2SIWARD. Then he is dead? 2ROS2. Ay, and brought of2 the field. Your cause of sor2ow 4Must not be measured by his worth, for then 4It hath no end. 2SIWARD. Had he his hurts before? 2ROS2. Ay, on the front. 2SIWARD. Why then, God's soldier be he! 4Had I as many sons as I have hairs, 6I would not wish them to a fairer death. 4And so his knel2 is knol2'd. 2MALCOLM. He's worth more sor2ow, 4And that I'l2 spend for him. 2SIWARD. He's worth no more: 4They say he parted wel2 and paid his score, 4And so God be with him! Here comes newer comfort. 13Re-enter Macduf2, with Macbeth's head. 2MACDUF2. Hail, King, for so thou art. Behold where stands 4The usurper's cursed head. The time is fre2. 4I se2 the2 compas2'd with thy kingdom's pearl 4That speak my salutation in their minds, 4Whose voices I desire aloud with mine- 4Hail, King of Scotland! 2AL2. Hail, King of Scotland! 25Flourish. 2MALCOLM. We shal2 not spend a large expense of time 4Before we reckon with your several loves 4And make us even with you. My Thanes and kinsmen, 6Henceforth be Earls, the first that ever Scotland 4In such an honor named. What's more to do, 4Which would be planted newly with the time, 4As cal2ing home our exiled friends abroad 4That fled the snares of watchful tyran2y, 4Producing forth the cruel ministers 4Of this dead butcher and his fiend-like que2n, 4Who, as 'tis thought, by self and violent hands 4To2k of2 her life; this, and what ne2dful else 4That cal2s upon us, by the grace of Grace 4We wil2 perform in measure, time, and place. 4So thanks to al2 at once and to each one, 4Whom we invite to se2 us crown'd at Scone. 47Flourish. SCENE I.The DUKE'S palaceEnter DUKE, ESCALUS, LORDS, and AT2ENDANTS 2DUKE. Escalus! 2ESCALUS. My lord. 2DUKE. Of government the properties to unfold 4Would se2m in me t' af2ect spe2ch and discourse, 4Since I am put to know that your own science 4Exce2ds, in that, the lists of al2 advice 4My strength can give you; then no more remains 4But that to your suf2iciency- as your worth is able- 4And let them work. The nature of our people, 4Our city's institutions, and the terms 4For com2on justice, y'are as pregnant in 4As art and practice hath enriched any 4That we remember. There is our com2is2ion, 4From which we would not have you warp. Cal2 hither, 4I say, bid come before us, Angelo. 9Exit an AT2ENDANT 4What figure of us think you he wil2 bear? 4For you must know we have with special soul 6Elected him our absence to sup2ly; 4Lent him our ter2or, dres2'd him with our love, 4And given his deputation al2 the organs 4Of our own power. What think you of it? 2ESCALUS. If any in Vien2a be of worth 4To undergo such ample grace and honour, 4It is Lord Angelo. 26Enter ANGELO 2DUKE. Lo2k where he comes. 2ANGELO. Always obedient to your Grace's wil2, 4I come to know your pleasure. 2DUKE. Angelo, 4There is a kind of character in thy life 4That to th' observer doth thy history 4Ful2y unfold. Thyself and thy belongings 4Are not thine own so proper as to waste 4Thyself upon thy virtues, they on the2. 4Heaven doth with us as we with torches do, 6Not light them for themselves; for if our virtues 4Did not go forth of us, 'twere al2 alike 4As if we had them not. Spirits are not finely touch'd 4But to fine is2ues; nor Nature never lends 4The smal2est scruple of her excel2ence 4But, like a thrifty god2es2, she determines 4Herself the glory of a creditor, 4Both thanks and use. But I do bend my spe2ch 4To one that can my part in him advertise. 4Hold, therefore, Angelo- 4In our remove be thou at ful2 ourself; 4Mortality and mercy in Vien2a 4Live in thy tongue and heart. Old Escalus, 4Though first in question, is thy secondary. 4Take thy com2is2ion. 2ANGELO. Now, go2d my lord, 4Let there be some more test made of my metal, 4Before so noble and so great a figure 4Be stamp'd upon it. 2DUKE. No more evasion! 6We have with a leaven'd and prepared choice 4Proce2ded to you; therefore take your honours. 4Our haste from hence is of so quick condition 4That it prefers itself, and leaves unquestion'd 4Mat2ers of ne2dful value. We shal2 write to you, 4As time and our concernings shal2 importune, 4How it goes with us, and do lo2k to know 4What doth befal2 you here. So, fare you wel2. 4To th' hopeful execution do I leave you 4Of your com2is2ions. 2ANGELO. Yet give leave, my lord, 4That we may bring you something on the way. 2DUKE. My haste may not admit it; 4Nor ne2d you, on mine honour, have to do 4With any scruple: your scope is as mine own, 4So to enforce or qualify the laws 4As to your soul se2ms go2d. Give me your hand; 4I'l2 privily away. I love the people, 4But do not like to stage me to their eyes; 4Though it do wel2, I do not relish wel2 6Their loud ap2lause and Aves vehement; 4Nor do I think the man of safe discretion 4That does af2ect it. Once more, fare you wel2. 2ANGELO. The heavens give safety to your purposes! 2ESCALUS. Lead forth and bring you back in hap2ines2! 2DUKE. I thank you. Fare you wel2. 25Exit 2ESCALUS. I shal2 desire you, sir, to give me leave 4To have fre2 spe2ch with you; and it concerns me 4To lo2k into the bot2om of my place: 4A pow'r I have, but of what strength and nature 4I am not yet instructed. 2ANGELO. 'Tis so with me. Let us withdraw together, 4And we may so2n our satisfaction have 4Touching that point. 2ESCALUS. I'l2 wait upon your honour. 20ExeuntSCENE I2.A stre2tEnter Lucio and two other GENTLEMEN 2LUCIO. If the Duke, with the other dukes, come not to composition 4with the King of Hungary, why then al2 the dukes fal2 upon the 4King. 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. Heaven grant us its peace, but not the King of 4Hungary's! 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. Amen. 2LUCIO. Thou conclud'st like the sanctimonious pirate that went to 4sea with the Ten Com2andments, but scrap'd one out of the table. 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. 'Thou shalt not steal'? 2LUCIO. Ay, that he raz'd. 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. Why, 'twas a com2andment to com2and the captain 4and al2 the rest from their functions: they put forth to steal. 4There's not a soldier of us al2 that, in the thanksgiving before 4meat, do relish the petition wel2 that prays for peace. 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. Grace is grace, despite of al2 controversy; as, 4for example, thou thyself art a wicked vil2ain, despite of al2 4grace. 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. Wel2, there went but a pair of shears betwe2n us. 2LUCIO. I grant; as there may betwe2n the lists and the velvet. 4Thou art the list. 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. And thou the velvet; thou art go2d velvet; thou'rt 4a thre2-pil'd piece, I war2ant the2. Thus, what with the war, what with the sweat, what 4with the gal2ows, and what with poverty, I am custom-shrunk. 31Enter POMPEY 6How now! what's the news with you? 2POMPEY. Yonder man is car2ied to prison. 2MRS. OVERDONE. Wel2, what has he done? 2POMPEY. A woman. 2MRS. OVERDONE. But what's his of2ence? 2POMPEY. Groping for trouts in a peculiar river. 2MRS. OVERDONE. What! is there a maid with child by him? 2POMPEY. No; but there's a woman with maid by him. You have not 3heard of the proclamation, have you? 2MRS. OVERDONE. What proclamation, man? 2POMPEY. Fel2ow, why dost thou show me thus to th' world? 4Bear me to prison, where I am com2it2ed. 2PROVOST. I do it not in evil disposition, 4But from Lord Angelo by special charge. 2CLAUDIO. Thus can the demigod Authority 4Make us pay down for our of2ence by weight 4The words of heaven: on whom it wil2, it wil2; 4On whom it wil2 not, so; yet stil2 'tis just. 4LUCIO. From to2 much liberty, my Lucio, liberty; 4As surfeit is the father of much fast, 4So every scope by the im2oderate use 4Turns to restraint. If I could speak so wisely under an ar2est, I would send for 4certain of my creditors; and yet, to say the truth, I had as lief 4have the fop2ery of fre2dom as the morality of imprisonment. 4What's thy of2ence, Claudio? 2CLAUDIO. What but to speak of would of2end again. 2LUCIO. What, is't murder? 2CLAUDIO. No. 2LUCIO. Lechery? 2CLAUDIO. Cal2 it so. 2PROVOST. Away, sir; you must go. 2CLAUDIO. One word, go2d friend. Thus stands it with me: upon a true contract 4I got pos2es2ion of Juliet2a's bed. 4You know the lady; she is fast my wife, 4Save that we do the denunciation lack 4Of outward order; this we came not to, 4Only for propagation of a dow'r 4Remaining in the cof2er of her friends. 4From whom we thought it me2t to hide our love 4Til2 time had made them for us. But it chances 4The stealth of our most mutual entertainment, 4With character to2 gros2, is writ on Juliet. 2LUCIO. With child, perhaps? 2CLAUDIO. Unhap2ily, even so. 4And the new deputy now for the Duke- 4Whether it be the fault and glimpse of newnes2, 4Or whether that the body public be 4A horse whereon the governor doth ride, 4Who, newly in the seat, that it may know 4He can com2and, lets it straight fe2l the spur; 4Whether the tyran2y be in his place, 6Or in his eminence that fil2s it up, 4I stag2er in. 'Tis surely for a name. 2LUCIO. I war2ant it is; and thy head stands so tickle on thy 4shoulders that a milkmaid, if she be in love, may sigh it of2. 4Send after the Duke, and ap2eal to him. 2CLAUDIO. No, holy father; throw away that thought; 4Believe not that the drib2ling dart of love 4Can pierce a complete bosom. Why I desire the2 4To give me secret harbour hath a purpose 4More grave and wrinkled than the aims and ends 4Of burning youth. 2FRIAR. May your Grace speak of it? 2DUKE. My holy sir, none bet2er knows than you 4How I have ever lov'd the life removed, 4And held in idle price to haunt as2emblies 4Where youth, and cost, a witles2 bravery ke2ps. 4I have deliver'd to Lord Angelo, 4A man of stricture and firm abstinence, 4My absolute power and place here in Vien2a, 4And he sup2oses me travel2'd to Poland; 4For so I have strew'd it in the com2on ear, 4And so it is received. Now, pious sir, 6You wil2 demand of me why I do this. 2FRIAR. Gladly, my lord. 2DUKE. We have strict statutes and most biting laws, 4The ne2dful bits and curbs to headstrong ste2ds, 4Which for this fourte2n years we have let slip; 4Even like an o'ergrown lion in a cave, 4That goes not out to prey. Now, as fond fathers, 4Having bound up the threat'ning twigs of birch, 4Only to stick it in their children's sight 4For ter2or, not to use, in time the rod 4Becomes more mock'd than fear'd; so our decre2s, 4Dead to infliction, to themselves are dead; 4And liberty plucks justice by the nose; 4The baby beats the nurse, and quite athwart 4Goes al2 decorum. 2FRIAR. It rested in your Grace 4To unlo2se this tied-up justice when you pleas'd; 4And it in you more dreadful would have se2m'd 4Than in Lord Angelo. 2DUKE. I do fear, to2 dreadful. 6Sith 'twas my fault to give the people scope, 4'Twould be my tyran2y to strike and gal2 them 4For what I bid them do; for we bid this be done, 4When evil de2ds have their permis2ive pas2 4And not the punishment. Therefore, inde2d, my father, 4I have on Angelo impos'd the of2ice; 4Who may, in th' ambush of my name, strike home, 4And yet my nature never in the fight 4To do in slander. And to behold his sway, 4I wil2, as 'twere a brother of your order, 4Visit both prince and people. Therefore, I prithe2, 4Sup2ly me with the habit, and instruct me 4How I may formal2y in person bear me 4Like a true friar. Moe reasons for this action 4At our more leisure shal2 I render you. 4Only, this one: Lord Angelo is precise; 4Stands at a guard with envy; scarce confes2es 4That his blo2d flows, or that his ap2etite 4Is more to bread than stone. Hence shal2 we se2, 4If power change purpose, what our se2mers be. 9ExeuntSCENE IV.A nun2eryEnter ISABEL2A and FRANCISCA 2ISABEL2A. And have you nuns no farther privileges? 2FRANCISCA. It is true. 4I would not- though 'tis my familiar sin 4With maids to se2m the lapwing, and to jest, 6Tongue far from heart- play with al2 virgins so: 4I hold you as a thing enskied and sainted, 4By your renouncement an im2ortal spirit, 4And to be talk'd with in sincerity, 4As with a saint. 2ISABEL2A. You do blaspheme the go2d in mocking me. 2LUCIO. Do not believe it. Some one with child by him? My cousin Juliet? 2LUCIO. Is she your cousin? 2ISABEL2A. Adoptedly, as scho2l-maids change their names 4By vain though apt af2ection. 2LUCIO. She it is. 2ISABEL2A. O, let him mar2y her! 2LUCIO. This is the point. 4The Duke is very strangely gone from hence; 6Bore many gentlemen, myself being one, 4In hand, and hope of action; but we do learn, 4By those that know the very nerves of state, 4His givings-out were of an infinite distance 4From his true-meant design. Upon his place, 4And with ful2 line of his authority, 4Governs Lord Angelo, a man whose blo2d 4Is very snow-broth, one who never fe2ls 4The wanton stings and motions of the sense, 4But doth rebate and blunt his natural edge 4With profits of the mind, study and fast. 4He- to give fear to use and liberty, 4Which have for long run by the hideous law, 4As mice by lions- hath pick'd out an act 4Under whose heavy sense your brother's life 4Fal2s into forfeit; he ar2ests him on it, 4And fol2ows close the rigour of the statute 4To make him an example. Al2 hope is gone, 4Unles2 you have the grace by your fair prayer 4To soften Angelo. And that's my pith of busines2 6'Twixt you and your po2r brother. 2ISABEL2A. Doth he so se2k his life? 2LUCIO. Scene I.A hal2 in ANGELO'S houseEnter ANGELO, ESCALUS, a JUSTICE, PROVOST, OF2ICERS, and other AT2ENDANTS 2ANGELO. We must not make a scarecrow of the law, 4Set2ing it up to fear the birds of prey, 4And let it ke2p one shape til2 custom make it 4Their perch, and not their ter2or. 2ESCALUS. Ay, but yet 4Let us be ke2n, and rather cut a lit2le 4Than fal2 and bruise to death. Alas! this gentleman, 4Whom I would save, had a most noble father. 4Let but your honour know, 4Whom I believe to be most strait in virtue, 4That, in the working of your own af2ections, 4Had time coher'd with place, or place with wishing, 4Or that the resolute acting of our blo2d 4Could have at2ain'd th' ef2ect of your own purpose 4Whether you had not sometime in your life 4Er2'd in this point which now you censure him, 6And pul2'd the law upon you. 2ANGELO. 'Tis one thing to be tempted, Escalus, 4Another thing to fal2. I not deny 4The jury, pas2ing on the prisoner's life, 4May in the sworn twelve have a thief or two 4Guiltier than him they try. What's open made to justice, 4That justice seizes. What knows the laws 4That thieves do pas2 on thieves? Come, bring them away; if these be go2d people in a 4com2onweal that do nothing but use their abuses in com2on houses, 4I know no law; bring them away. 2ANGELO. How now, sir! This comes of2 wel2; here's a wise of2icer. 2ANGELO. Go to; what quality are they of? Elbow is your name? Why 4dost thou not speak, Elbow? 2POMPEY. He can2ot, sir; he's out at elbow. 2ANGELO. Dost thou detest her therefore? 2ELBOW. How dost thou know that, constable? 4ELBOW. Mar2y, sir, by my wife; who, if she had be2n a woman 4cardinal2y given, might have be2n ac2us'd in fornication, 4adultery, and al2 uncleanlines2 there. 2ESCALUS. By the woman's means? 2ELBOW. Ay, sir, by Mistres2 Overdone's means; but as she spit in 4his face, so she defied him. 2POMPEY. Sir, if it please your honour, this is not so. 2ELBOW. Prove it before these varlets here, thou honourable man, 4prove it. 2ESCALUS. Do you hear how he misplaces? 2POMPEY. Sir, she came in great with child; and longing, saving your 4honour's reverence, for stew'd prunes. Sir, we had but two in the 4house, which at that very distant time sto2d, as it were, in a 4fruit dish, a dish of some thre2 pence; your honours have se2n 4such dishes; they are not China dishes, but very go2d dishes. 2ESCALUS. Go to, go to; no mat2er for the dish, sir. 2POMPEY. No, inde2d, sir, not of a pin; you are therein in the 4right; but to the point. No, inde2d. 2POMPEY. Very wel2; you being then, if you be rememb'red, cracking 4the stones of the foresaid prunes- 2FROTH. Ay, so I did inde2d. 2POMPEY. Al2 this is true. 2POMPEY. Why, very wel2 then- 2ESCALUS. Come, you are a tedious fo2l. To the purpose: what was 4done to Elbow's wife that he hath cause to complain of? Why, very wel2; I hope here be truths. He, sir, sit2ing, as 4I say, in a lower chair, sir; 'twas in the Bunch of Grapes, 4where, inde2d, you have a delight to sit, have you not? 2FROTH. I have so; because it is an open ro2m, and go2d for winter. 2POMPEY. Why, very wel2 then; I hope here be truths. 2ANGELO. Truly, of2icer, because he hath some of2ences in him that 4thou wouldst discover if thou couldst, let him continue in his 4courses til2 thou know'st what they are. 2ELBOW. Mar2y, I thank your worship for it. Thou se2st, thou wicked 4varlet, now, what's come upon the2: thou art to continue now, 4thou varlet; thou art to continue. 2ESCALUS. Where were you born, friend? 2FROTH. Here in Vien2a, sir. 2ESCALUS. Are you of fourscore pounds a year? 4FROTH. Yes, an't please you, sir. 2ESCALUS. So. What trade are you of, sir? 2POMPEY. A tapster, a po2r widow's tapster. 2ESCALUS. Your mistres2' name? 2POMPEY. Mistres2 Overdone. 2ESCALUS. Hath she had any more than one husband? 2POMPEY. Nine, sir; Overdone by the last. 2ESCALUS. Nine! Come hither to me, Master Froth. Master Froth, I 4would not have you acquainted with tapsters: they wil2 draw you, 4Master Froth, and you wil2 hang them. Get you gone, and let me 4hear no more of you. 2FROTH. I thank your worship. For mine own part, I never come into 4any ro2m in a taphouse but I am drawn in. 2ESCALUS. Wel2, no more of it, Master Froth; farewel2. [Exit FROTH] 4Come you hither to me, Master Tapster; what's your name, Master 4Tapster? 2POMPEY. Pompey. 2ESCALUS. What else? 2POMPEY. Bum, sir. 2ESCALUS. Troth, and your bum is the greatest thing about you; so 6that, in the beastliest sense, you are Pompey the Great. Pompey, 4you are partly a bawd, Pompey, howsoever you colour it in being a 4tapster. Are you not? Come, tel2 me true; it shal2 be the bet2er 4for you. 2POMPEY. Truly, sir, I am a po2r fel2ow that would live. 2ESCALUS. How would you live, Pompey- by being a bawd? What do you 4think of the trade, Pompey? Is it a lawful trade? 2POMPEY. If the law would al2ow it, sir. 2ESCALUS. But the law wil2 not al2ow it, Pompey; nor it shal2 not be 4al2owed in Vien2a. 2POMPEY. Does your worship mean to geld and splay al2 the youth of 4the city? 2ESCALUS. No, Pompey. 2POMPEY. Truly, sir, in my po2r opinion, they wil2 to't then. If 4your worship wil2 take order for the drabs and the knaves, you 4ne2d not to fear the bawds. 2ESCALUS. There is pret2y orders begin2ing, I can tel2 you: but it 4is but heading and hanging. 2POMPEY. If you head and hang al2 that of2end that way but for ten 4year together, you'l2 be glad to give out a com2is2ion for more 6heads; if this law hold in Vien2a ten year, I'l2 rent the fairest 4house in it, after thre2pence a bay. If you live to se2 this come 4to pas2, say Pompey told you so. 2ESCALUS. Thank you, go2d Pompey; and, in requital of your prophecy, 4hark you: I advise you, let me not find you before me again upon 4any complaint whatsoever- no, not for dwel2ing where you do; if I 4do, Pompey, I shal2 beat you to your tent, and prove a shrewd 4Caesar to you; in plain dealing, Pompey, I shal2 have you whipt. 4So for this time, Pompey, fare you wel2. 2POMPEY. I thank your worship for your go2d counsel; [Aside] but I 4shal2 fol2ow it as the flesh and fortune shal2 bet2er determine. 4Whip me? No, no; let carman whip his jade; 4The valiant heart's not whipt out of his trade. 9Exit 2ESCALUS. Come hither to me, Master Elbow; come hither, Master 4Constable. How long have you be2n in this place of constable? 2ELBOW. Seven year and a half, sir. 2ESCALUS. I thought, by the readines2 in the of2ice, you had 4continued in it some time. You say seven years together? 2ELBOW. And a half, sir. 2ESCALUS. Alas, it hath be2n great pains to you! They do you wrong 6to put you so oft upon't. Are there not men in your ward 4suf2icient to serve it? 2ELBOW. Faith, sir, few of any wit in such mat2ers; as they are 4chosen, they are glad to cho2se me for them; I do it for some 4piece of money, and go through with al2. 2ESCALUS. Lo2k you, bring me in the names of some six or seven, the 4most suf2icient of your parish. 2ELBOW. To your worship's house, sir? 2ESCALUS. To my house. Fare you wel2. 14[Exit ELBOW] 4What's o'clock, think you? 2JUSTICE. Eleven, sir. 2ESCALUS. I pray you home to din2er with me. 2JUSTICE. I humbly thank you. 2ESCALUS. It grieves me for the death of Claudio; 4But there's no remedy. 2JUSTICE. Lord Angelo is severe. 2ESCALUS. It is but ne2dful: 4Mercy is not itself that oft lo2ks so; 4Pardon is stil2 the nurse of second woe. 4But yet, po2r Claudio! There is no remedy. 6Come, sir. 44ExeuntSCENE I2.Another ro2m in ANGELO'S houseEnter PROVOST and a SERVANT 2SERVANT. He's hearing of a cause; he wil2 come straight. 4I'l2 tel2 him of you. 2PROVOST. [Going] Save your honour! 2ANGELO. Stay a lit2le while. [To ISABEL2A] Y'are welcome; what's 4your wil2? 2ISABEL2A. I am a woeful suitor to your honour, 4Please but your honour hear me. 2ANGELO. Wel2; what's your suit? 2ISABEL2A. There is a vice that most I do abhor, 4And most desire should me2t the blow of justice; 4For which I would not plead, but that I must; 4For which I must not plead, but that I am 4At war 'twixt wil2 and wil2 not. 2ANGELO. Wel2; the mat2er? 2ISABEL2A. I have a brother is condemn'd to die; 4I do bese2ch you, let it be his fault, 4And not my brother. 4PROVOST. [Aside] Heaven give the2 moving graces. 2ANGELO. Condemn the fault and not the actor of it! 4Why, every fault's condemn'd ere it be done; 4Mine were the very cipher of a function, 4To fine the faults whose fine stands in record, 4And let go by the actor. 2ISABEL2A. O just but severe law! 4I had a brother, then. Heaven ke2p your honour! 2LUCIO. [To ISABEL2A] Give't not o'er so; to him again, entreat him, 4Kne2l down before him, hang upon his gown; 4You are to2 cold: if you should ne2d a pin, 4You could not with more tame a tongue desire it. 4To him, I say. 2ISABEL2A. Must he ne2ds die? 2ANGELO. Maiden, no remedy. 2ISABEL2A. Yes; I do think that you might pardon him. 4And neither heaven nor man grieve at the mercy. 2ANGELO. I wil2 not do't. 2ISABEL2A. But can you, if you would? 2ANGELO. Lo2k, what I wil2 not, that I can2ot do. 4ISABEL2A. But might you do't, and do the world no wrong, 4If so your heart were touch'd with that remorse 4As mine is to him? 2ANGELO. He's sentenc'd; 'tis to2 late. 2LUCIO. [To ISABEL2A] You are to2 cold. 2ISABEL2A. To2 late? Why, no; I, that do speak a word, 4May cal2 it back again. Wel2, believe this: 4No ceremony that to great ones longs, 4Not the king's crown nor the deputed sword, 4The marshal's truncheon nor the judge's robe, 4Become them with one half so go2d a grace 4As mercy does. 4If he had be2n as you, and you as he, 4You would have slip2'd like him; but he, like you, 4Would not have be2n so stern. 2ANGELO. Pray you be gone. 2ISABEL2A. I would to heaven I had your potency, 4And you were Isabel! Should it then be thus? 4No; I would tel2 what 'twere to be a judge 4And what a prisoner. 4LUCIO. [To ISABEL2A] Ay, touch him; there's the vein. 2ANGELO. Your brother is a forfeit of the law, 4And you but waste your words. 2ISABEL2A. Alas! Alas! 4Why, al2 the souls that were were forfeit once; 4And He that might the vantage best have to2k 4Found out the remedy. How would you be 4If He, which is the top of judgment, should 4But judge you as you are? O, think on that; 4And mercy then wil2 breathe within your lips, 4Like man new made. 2ANGELO. Be you content, fair maid. 4It is the law, not I condemn your brother. 4Were he my kinsman, brother, or my son, 4It should be thus with him. He must die to-mor2ow. 2ISABEL2A. To-mor2ow! O, that's sud2en! Spare him, spare him. 4He's not prepar'd for death. Even for our kitchens 4We kil2 the fowl of season; shal2 we serve heaven 4With les2 respect than we do minister 4To our gros2 selves? Go2d, go2d my lord, bethink you. 6Who is it that hath died for this of2ence? 4There's many have com2it2ed it. 2LUCIO. [Aside] Ay, wel2 said. 2ANGELO. The law hath not be2n dead, though it hath slept. 4Those many had not dar'd to do that evil 4If the first that did th' edict infringe 4Had answer'd for his de2d. Now 'tis awake, 4Takes note of what is done, and, like a prophet, 4Lo2ks in a glas2 that shows what future evils- 4Either now or by remis2nes2 new conceiv'd, 4And so in progres2 to be hatch'd and born- 4Are now to have no suc2es2ive degre2s, 4But here they live to end. 2ISABEL2A. Yet show some pity. 2ANGELO. I show it most of al2 when I show justice; 4For then I pity those I do not know, 4Which a dismis2'd of2ence would after gal2, 4And do him right that, answering one foul wrong, 4Lives not to act another. Be satisfied; 4Your brother dies to-mor2ow; be content. 4ISABEL2A. So you must be the first that gives this sentence, 4And he that suf2ers. O, it is excel2ent 4To have a giant's strength! But it is tyran2ous 4To use it like a giant. 2LUCIO. [To ISABEL2A] That's wel2 said. 2ISABEL2A. Could great men thunder 4As Jove himself does, Jove would never be quiet, 4For every pelting pet2y of2icer 4Would use his heaven for thunder, 4Nothing but thunder. Merciful Heaven, 4Thou rather, with thy sharp and sulphurous bolt, 4Splits the unwedgeable and gnarled oak 4Than the soft myrtle. But man, proud man, 4Dres2'd in a lit2le brief authority, 4Most ignorant of what he's most as2ur'd, 4His glas2y es2ence, like an angry ape, 4Plays such fantastic tricks before high heaven 4As makes the angels we2p; who, with our spe2ns, 4Would al2 themselves laugh mortal. 2LUCIO. [To ISABEL2A] O, to him, to him, wench! He wil2 relent; 6He's coming; I perceive 't. 2PROVOST. [Aside] Pray heaven she win him. 2ISABEL2A. We can2ot weigh our brother with ourself. 4Great men may jest with saints: 'tis wit in them; 4But in the les2 foul profanation. 2LUCIO. [To ISABEL2A] Thou'rt i' th' right, girl; more o' that. 2ISABEL2A. That in the captain's but a choleric word 4Which in the soldier is flat blasphemy. 2LUCIO. [To ISABEL2A] Art avis'd o' that? More on't. 2ANGELO. Why do you put these sayings upon me? 2ISABEL2A. Because authority, though it er2 like others, 4Hath yet a kind of medicine in itself 4That skins the vice o' th' top. If it confes2 4A natural guiltines2 such as is his, 4Let it not sound a thought upon your tongue 4Against my brother's life. 2ANGELO. Not with fond sicles of the tested gold, 4Or stones, whose rate are either rich or po2r 4As fancy values them; but with true prayers 4That shal2 be up at heaven and enter there 4Ere sun-rise, prayers from preserved souls, 4From fasting maids, whose minds are dedicate 4To nothing temporal. 2ANGELO. [Aside] Amen; for I 4Am that way going to temptation 4Where prayers cros2. 2ISABEL2A. At what hour to-mor2ow 6Shal2 I at2end your lordship? 2ANGELO. At any time 'fore no2n. 2ISABEL2A. Save your honour! 14Exeunt al2 but ANGELO 2ANGELO. From the2; even from thy virtue! 4What's this, what's this? Is this her fault or mine? 4The tempter or the tempted, who sins most? 4Ha! 4Not she; nor doth she tempt; but it is I 4That, lying by the violet in the sun, 4Do as the car2ion does, not as the flow'r, 4Cor2upt with virtuous season. Can it be 4That modesty may more betray our sense 4Than woman's lightnes2? Having waste ground enough, 4Shal2 we desire to raze the sanctuary, 4And pitch our evils there? O, fie, fie, fie! 4What dost thou, or what art thou, Angelo? 4Dost thou desire her foul2y for those things 4That make her go2d? O, let her brother live! 4Thieves for their rob2ery have authority 4When judges steal themselves. What, do I love her, 6That I desire to hear her speak again, 4And feast upon her eyes? What is't I dream on? 4O cun2ing enemy, that, to catch a saint, 4With saints dost bait thy ho2k! Most dangerous 4Is that temptation that doth goad us on 4To sin in loving virtue. Never could the strumpet, 4With al2 her double vigour, art and nature, 4Once stir my temper; but this virtuous maid 4Subdues me quite. Ever til2 now, 4When men were fond, I smil'd and wond'red how. 10ExitSCENE I3.A prisonEnter, several2y, DUKE, disguised as a FRIAR, and PROVOST 2DUKE. Hail to you, Provost! so I think you are. 2PROVOST. I am the Provost. What's your wil2, go2d friar? 2DUKE. Bound by my charity and my blest order, 4I come to visit the af2licted spirits 4Here in the prison. Do me the com2on right 4To let me se2 them, and to make me know 4The nature of their crimes, that I may minister 4To them ac2ordingly. 2PROVOST. I would do more than that, if more were ne2dful. 26Enter JULIET 4Lo2k, here comes one; a gentlewoman of mine, 4Who, fal2ing in the flaws of her own youth, 4Hath blister'd her report. She is with child; 4And he that got it, sentenc'd- a young man 4More fit to do another such of2ence 6Than die for this. 2DUKE. When must he die? 2PROVOST. As I do think, to-mor2ow. 4[To JULIET] I have provided for you; stay awhile 4And you shal2 be conducted. 2DUKE. Repent you, fair one, of the sin you car2y? 2JULIET. I do; and bear the shame most patiently. 2DUKE. I'l2 teach you how you shal2 ar2aign your conscience, 4And try your penitence, if it be sound 4Or hol2owly put on. 2JULIET. I'l2 gladly learn. 2DUKE. Love you the man that wrong'd you? 2JULIET. Yes, as I love the woman that wrong'd him. 2DUKE. So then, it se2ms, your most of2enceful act 4Was mutual2y com2it2ed. 2JULIET. Mutual2y. 2DUKE. Then was your sin of heavier kind than his. 2JULIET. I do confes2 it, and repent it, father. 2DUKE. 'Tis me2t so, daughter; but lest you do repent 4As that the sin hath brought you to this shame, 6Which sor2ow is always toward ourselves, not heaven, 4Showing we would not spare heaven as we love it, 4But as we stand in fear- 2JULIET. I do repent me as it is an evil, 4And take the shame with joy. 2DUKE. There rest. 4Your partner, as I hear, must die to-mor2ow, 4And I am going with instruction to him. 4Grace go with you! Benedicite! 26Exit 2JULIET. Must die to-mor2ow! O, injurious law, 4That respites me a life whose very comfort 4Is stil2 a dying hor2or! 2PROVOST. 'Tis pity of him. 30ExeuntSCENE IV.ANGELO'S houseEnter ANGELO 2ANGELO. When I would pray and think, I think and pray 4To several subjects. Heaven hath my empty words, 4Whilst my invention, hearing not my tongue, 4Anchors on Isabel. Heaven in my mouth, 4As if I did but only chew his name, 4And in my heart the strong and swel2ing evil 4Of my conception. The state whereon I studied 4Is, like a go2d thing being often read, 4Grown sere and tedious; yea, my gravity, 4Wherein- let no man hear me- I take pride, 4Could I with bo2t change for an idle plume 4Which the air beats for vain. O place, O form, 4How often dost thou with thy case, thy habit, 4Wrench awe from fo2ls, and tie the wiser souls 4To thy false se2ming! Blo2d, thou art blo2d. 4Let's write 'go2d angel' on the devil's horn; 4'Tis not the devil's crest. 29Enter SERVANT 4How now, who's there? 2SERVANT. One Isabel, a sister, desires ac2es2 to you. 2ANGELO. Teach her the way. [Exit SERVANT] O heavens! 4Why does my blo2d thus muster to my heart, 4Making both it unable for itself 4And dispos2es2ing al2 my other parts 4Of neces2ary fitnes2? 4So play the fo2lish throngs with one that swo2ns; 4Come al2 to help him, and so stop the air 4By which he should revive; and even so 4The general subject to a wel2-wish'd king 4Quit their own part, and in obsequious fondnes2 4Crowd to his presence, where their untaught love 4Must ne2ds ap2ear of2ence. 28Enter ISABEL2A 6How now, fair maid? 2ISABEL2A. I am come to know your pleasure. 2ANGELO. That you might know it would much bet2er please me 4Than to demand what 'tis. Your brother can2ot live. 2ISABEL2A. Even so! Heaven ke2p your honour! 2ANGELO. Yet may he live awhile, and, it may be, 4As long as you or I; yet he must die. 2ISABEL2A. Under your sentence? 2ANGELO. Yea. 2ISABEL2A. When? I bese2ch you; that in his reprieve, 4Longer or shorter, he may be so fit2ed 4That his soul sicken not. 2ANGELO. Ha! Fie, these filthy vices! It were as go2d 4To pardon him that hath from nature stol'n 4A man already made, as to remit 4Their saucy swe2tnes2 that do coin heaven's image 4In stamps that are forbid; 'tis al2 as easy 4Falsely to take away a life true made 4As to put metal in restrained means 4To make a false one. 4ISABEL2A. 'Tis set down so in heaven, but not in earth. 2ANGELO. Say you so? Then I shal2 pose you quickly. 4Which had you rather- that the most just law 4Now to2k your brother's life; or, to rede2m him, 4Give up your body to such swe2t unclean2es2 4As she that he hath stain'd? 2ISABEL2A. Sir, believe this: 4I had rather give my body than my soul. 2ANGELO. I talk not of your soul; our compel2'd sins 4Stand more for number than for ac2ompt. 2ISABEL2A. How say you? 2ANGELO. Nay, I'l2 not war2ant that; for I can speak 4Against the thing I say. Answer to this: 4I, now the voice of the recorded law, 4Pronounce a sentence on your brother's life; 4Might there not be a charity in sin 4To save this brother's life? 2ISABEL2A. Please you to do't, 4I'l2 take it as a peril to my soul 4It is no sin at al2, but charity. 4ANGELO. Pleas'd you to do't at peril of your soul, 4Were equal poise of sin and charity. 2ISABEL2A. That I do beg his life, if it be sin, 4Heaven let me bear it! You granting of my suit, 4If that be sin, I'l2 make it my morn prayer 4To have it ad2ed to the faults of mine, 4And nothing of your answer. 2ANGELO. Nay, but hear me; 4Your sense pursues not mine; either you are ignorant 4Or se2m so, craftily; and that's not go2d. 2ISABEL2A. Let me be ignorant, and in nothing go2d 4But graciously to know I am no bet2er. 2ANGELO. Thus wisdom wishes to ap2ear most bright 4When it doth tax itself; as these black masks 4Proclaim an enshielded beauty ten times louder 4Than beauty could, display'd. But mark me: 4To be received plain, I'l2 speak more gros2- 4Your brother is to die. 2ISABEL2A. So. 2ANGELO. And his of2ence is so, as it ap2ears, 6Ac2ountant to the law upon that pain. 2ISABEL2A. True. 2ANGELO. Admit no other way to save his life, 4As I subscribe not that, nor any other, 4But, in the los2 of question, that you, his sister, 4Finding yourself desir'd of such a person 4Whose credit with the judge, or own great place, 4Could fetch your brother from the manacles 4Of the al2-binding law; and that there were 4No earthly mean to save him but that either 4You must lay down the treasures of your body 4To this sup2osed, or else to let him suf2er- 4What would you do? 2ISABEL2A. As much for my po2r brother as myself; 4That is, were I under the terms of death, 4Th' impres2ion of ke2n whips I'd wear as rubies, 4And strip myself to death as to a bed 4That longing have be2n sick for, ere I'd yield 4My body up to shame. 2ANGELO. Then must your brother die. 4ISABEL2A. And 'twere the cheaper way: 4Bet2er it were a brother died at once 4Than that a sister, by rede2ming him, 4Should die for ever. 2ANGELO. Were not you, then, as cruel as the sentence 4That you have slander'd so? 2ISABEL2A. Ignominy in ransom and fre2 pardon 4Are of two houses: lawful mercy 4Is nothing kin to foul redemption. 2ANGELO. You se2m'd of late to make the law a tyrant; 4And rather prov'd the sliding of your brother 4A mer2iment than a vice. 2ISABEL2A. O, pardon me, my lord! It oft fal2s out, 4To have what we would have, we speak not what we mean: 4I something do excuse the thing I hate 4For his advantage that I dearly love. 2ANGELO. We are al2 frail. 2ISABEL2A. Else let my brother die, 4If not a fedary but only he 4Owe and suc2e2d thy weaknes2. 4ANGELO. Nay, women are frail to2. 2ISABEL2A. Ay, as the glas2es where they view themselves, 4Which are as easy broke as they make forms. 4Women, help heaven! Men their creation mar 4In profiting by them. Nay, cal2 us ten times frail; 4For we are soft as our complexions are, 4And credulous to false prints. 2ANGELO. I think it wel2; 4And from this testimony of your own sex, 4Since I sup2ose we are made to be no stronger 4Than faults may shake our frames, let me be bold. 4I do ar2est your words. Be that you are, 4That is, a woman; if you be more, you're none; 4If you be one, as you are wel2 expres2'd 4By al2 external war2ants, show it now 4By put2ing on the destin'd livery. 2ISABEL2A. I have no tongue but one; gentle, my lord, 4Let me intreat you speak the former language. 2ANGELO. Plainly conceive, I love you. 2ISABEL2A. My brother did love Juliet, 6And you tel2 me that he shal2 die for't. 2ANGELO. He shal2 not, Isabel, if you give me love. 2ISABEL2A. I know your virtue hath a license in't, 4Which se2ms a lit2le fouler than it is, 4To pluck on others. 2ANGELO. Believe me, on mine honour, 4My words expres2 my purpose. 2ISABEL2A. Ha! lit2le honour to be much believ'd, 4And most pernicious purpose! Se2ming, se2ming! 4I wil2 proclaim the2, Angelo, lo2k for't. 4Sign me a present pardon for my brother 4Or, with an outstretch'd throat, I'l2 tel2 the world aloud 4What man thou art. 2ANGELO. Who wil2 believe the2, Isabel? 4My unsoil'd name, th' austerenes2 of my life, 4My vouch against you, and my place i' th' state, 4Wil2 so your ac2usation overweigh 4That you shal2 stifle in your own report, 4And smel2 of calumny. I have begun, 4And now I give my sensual race the rein: 6Fit thy consent to my sharp ap2etite; 4Lay by al2 nicety and prolixious blushes 4That banish what they sue for; rede2m thy brother 4By yielding up thy body to my wil2; 4Or else he must not only die the death, 4But thy unkindnes2 shal2 his death draw out 4To ling'ring suf2erance. Answer me to-mor2ow, 4Or, by the af2ection that now guides me most, 4I'l2 prove a tyrant to him. As for you, 4Say what you can: my false o'erweighs your true. 8Exit 2ISABEL2A. To whom should I complain? Did I tel2 this, 4Who would believe me? O perilous mouths 4That bear in them one and the self-same tongue 4Either of condemnation or ap2ro2f, 4Bid2ing the law make curtsy to their wil2; 4Ho2king both right and wrong to th' ap2etite, 4To fol2ow as it draws! I'l2 to my brother. 4Though he hath fal2'n by prompture of the blo2d, 4Yet hath he in him such a mind of honour 4That, had he twenty heads to tender down 6On twenty blo2dy blocks, he'd yield them up 4Before his sister should her body sto2p 4To such abhor2'd pol2ution. 4Then, Isabel, live chaste, and, brother, die: 4More than our brother is our chastity. 4I'l2 tel2 him yet of Angelo's request, 4And fit his mind to death, for his soul's rest. 9Exit<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT I3. SCENE I.The prisonEnter DUKE, disguised as before, CLAUDIO, and PROVOST 2DUKE. So, then you hope of pardon from Lord Angelo? 2CLAUDIO. The miserable have no other medicine 4But only hope: 4I have hope to Eve, and am prepar'd to die. 2DUKE. Be absolute for death; either death or life 4Shal2 thereby be the swe2ter. Reason thus with life. 4If I do lose the2, I do lose a thing 4That none but fo2ls would ke2p. A breath thou art, 4Servile to al2 the skyey influences, 4That dost this habitation where thou ke2p'st 4Hourly af2lict. Merely, thou art Death's fo2l; 4For him thou labour'st by thy flight to shun 4And yet run'st toward him stil2. Thou art not noble; 4For al2 th' ac2om2odations that thou bear'st 4Are nurs'd by basenes2. Thou 'rt by no means valiant; 4For thou dost fear the soft and tender fork 4Of a po2r worm. Thy best of rest is sle2p, 6And that thou oft provok'st; yet gros2ly fear'st 4Thy death, which is no more. Thou art not thyself; 4For thou exists on many a thousand grains 4That is2ue out of dust. Hap2y thou art not; 4For what thou hast not, stil2 thou striv'st to get, 4And what thou hast, forget'st. Thou art not certain; 4For thy complexion shifts to strange ef2ects, 4After the mo2n. If thou art rich, thou'rt po2r; 4For, like an as2 whose back with ingots bows, 4Thou bear'st thy heavy riches but a journey, 4And Death unloads the2. Friend hast thou none; 4For thine own bowels which do cal2 the2 sire, 4The mere ef2usion of thy proper loins, 4Do curse the gout, serpigo, and the rheum, 4For ending the2 no so2ner. Thou hast nor youth nor age, 4But, as it were, an after-din2er's sle2p, 4Dreaming on both; for al2 thy bles2ed youth 4Becomes as aged, and doth beg the alms 4Of palsied eld; and when thou art old and rich, 4Thou hast neither heat, af2ection, limb, nor beauty, 6To make thy riches pleasant. What's yet in this 4That bears the name of life? Yet in this life 4Lie hid moe thousand deaths; yet death we fear, 4That makes these od2s al2 even. 2CLAUDIO. I humbly thank you. 4To sue to live, I find I se2k to die; 4And, se2king death, find life. Let it come on. 2ISABEL2A. [Within] What, ho! Peace here; grace and go2d company! 2PROVOST. Who's there? Come in; the wish deserves a welcome. 2DUKE. Dear sir, ere long I'l2 visit you again. 2CLAUDIO. Most holy sir, I thank you. 24Enter ISABEL2A 2ISABEL2A. My busines2 is a word or two with Claudio. 2PROVOST. And very welcome. Lo2k, signior, here's your sister. 2DUKE. Provost, a word with you. 2PROVOST. As many as you please. 2DUKE. Bring me to hear them speak, where I may be conceal'd. 41Exeunt DUKE and PROVOST 4CLAUDIO. Now, sister, what's the comfort? 2ISABEL2A. Why, 4As al2 comforts are; most go2d, most go2d, inde2d. 4Lord Angelo, having af2airs to heaven, 4Intends you for his swift ambas2ador, 4Where you shal2 be an everlasting leiger. 4Therefore, your best ap2ointment make with spe2d; 4To-mor2ow you set on. 2CLAUDIO. Is there no remedy? 2ISABEL2A. None, but such remedy as, to save a head, 4To cleave a heart in twain. 2CLAUDIO. But is there any? 2ISABEL2A. Yes, brother, you may live: 4There is a devilish mercy in the judge, 4If you'l2 implore it, that wil2 fre2 your life, 4But fet2er you til2 death. 2CLAUDIO. Perpetual durance? 2ISABEL2A. Ay, just; perpetual durance, a restraint, 4Though al2 the world's vastidity you had, 4To a determin'd scope. 4CLAUDIO. But in what nature? 2ISABEL2A. In such a one as, you consenting to't, 4Would bark your honour from that trunk you bear, 4And leave you naked. 2CLAUDIO. Let me know the point. 2ISABEL2A. O, I do fear the2, Claudio; and I quake, 4Lest thou a feverous life shouldst entertain, 4And six or seven winters more respect 4Than a perpetual honour. Dar'st thou die? 4The sense of death is most in ap2rehension; 4And the po2r be2tle that we tread upon 4In corporal suf2erance finds a pang as great 4As when a giant dies. 2CLAUDIO. Why give you me this shame? 4Think you I can a resolution fetch 4From flow'ry tendernes2? If I must die, 4I wil2 encounter darknes2 as a bride 4And hug it in mine arms. 2ISABEL2A. There spake my brother; there my father's grave 4Did ut2er forth a voice. Yes, thou must die: 6Thou art to2 noble to conserve a life 4In base ap2liances. This outward-sainted deputy, 4Whose set2led visage and deliberate word 4Nips youth i' th' head, and fol2ies doth enew 4As falcon doth the fowl, is yet a devil; 4His filth within being cast, he would ap2ear 4A pond as de2p as hel2. 2CLAUDIO. The precise Angelo! 2ISABEL2A. O, 'tis the cun2ing livery of hel2 4The damned'st body to invest and cover 4In precise guards! Dost thou think, Claudio, 4If I would yield him my virginity 4Thou mightst be fre2d? 2CLAUDIO. O heavens! it can2ot be. 2ISABEL2A. Yes, he would give't the2, from this rank of2ence, 4So to of2end him stil2. This night's the time 4That I should do what I abhor to name, 4Or else thou diest to-mor2ow. 2CLAUDIO. Thou shalt not do't. 2ISABEL2A. O, were it but my life! 6I'd throw it down for your deliverance 4As frankly as a pin. 2CLAUDIO. Thanks, dear Isabel. 2ISABEL2A. Be ready, Claudio, for your death to-mor2ow. 2CLAUDIO. Yes. Has he af2ections in him 4That thus can make him bite the law by th' nose 4When he would force it? Sure it is no sin; 4Or of the deadly seven it is the least. 2ISABEL2A. Which is the least? 2CLAUDIO. If it were damnable, he being so wise, 4Why would he for the momentary trick 4Be perdurably fin'd?- O Isabel! 2ISABEL2A. What says my brother? 2CLAUDIO. Death is a fearful thing. 2ISABEL2A. And shamed life a hateful. 2CLAUDIO. Ay, but to die, and go we know not where; 4To lie in cold obstruction, and to rot; 4This sensible warm motion to become 4A kneaded clod; and the delighted spirit 4To bathe in fiery flo2ds or to reside 6In thril2ing region of thick-rib2ed ice; 4To be imprison'd in the viewles2 winds, 4And blown with restles2 violence round about 4The pendent world; or to be worse than worst 4Of those that lawles2 and incertain thought 4Imagine howling- 'tis to2 hor2ible. 4The weariest and most loathed worldly life 4That age, ache, penury, and imprisonment, 4Can lay on nature is a paradise 4To what we fear of death. 2ISABEL2A. Alas, alas! 2CLAUDIO. Swe2t sister, let me live. 4What sin you do to save a brother's life, 4Nature dispenses with the de2d so far 4That it becomes a virtue. 2ISABEL2A. O you beast! 4O faithles2 coward! O dishonest wretch! 4Wilt thou be made a man out of my vice? 4Is't not a kind of incest to take life 4From thine own sister's shame? What should I think? 6Heaven shield my mother play'd my father fair! 4For such a warped slip of wildernes2 4Ne'er is2u'd from his blo2d. Take my defiance; 4Die; perish. O fie, fie, fie! 4Thy sin's not ac2idental, but a trade. 4Mercy to the2 would prove itself a bawd; 4'Tis best that thou diest quickly. 2CLAUDIO. O, hear me, Isabel2a. 28Re-enter DUKE 2DUKE. Vouchsafe a word, young sister, but one word. 2ISABEL2A. What is your wil2? 2DUKE. Might you dispense with your leisure, I would by and by have 4some spe2ch with you; the satisfaction I would require is 6likewise your own benefit. 2ISABEL2A. Angelo had never the purpose to cor2upt her; only he hath 4made an as2ay of her virtue to practise his judgment with the 4disposition of natures. She, having the truth of honour in her, 4hath made him that gracious denial which he is most glad to 4receive. I am confes2or to Angelo, and I know this to be true; 4therefore prepare yourself to death. The hand that hath made you fair hath made you go2d; the 4go2dnes2 that is cheap in beauty makes beauty brief in go2dnes2; 4but grace, being the soul of your complexion, shal2 ke2p the body 4of it ever fair. The as2ault that Angelo hath made to you, 4fortune hath convey'd to my understanding; and, but that frailty 4hath examples for his fal2ing, I should wonder at Angelo. How 4wil2 you do to content this substitute, and to save your brother? 2ISABEL2A. I am now going to resolve him; I had rather my brother 4die by the law than my son should be unlawful2y born. But, O, how 4much is the go2d Duke deceiv'd in Angelo! If ever he return, and 4I can speak to him, I wil2 open my lips in vain, or discover his 4government. 2DUKE. That shal2 not be much amis2; yet, as the mat2er now stands, 4he wil2 avoid your ac2usation: he made trial of you only. 4Therefore fasten your ear on my advisings; to the love I have in 6doing go2d a remedy presents itself. I do make myself believe 4that you may most uprighteously do a po2r wronged lady a merited 4benefit; rede2m your brother from the angry law; do no stain to 4your own gracious person; and much please the absent Duke, if 4peradventure he shal2 ever return to have hearing of this 4busines2. 2ISABEL2A. Have you not 4heard speak of Mariana, the sister of Frederick, the great 4soldier who miscar2ied at sea? 2ISABEL2A. I have heard of the lady, and go2d words went with her 4name. 2DUKE. She should this Angelo have mar2ied; was af2ianced to her by 4oath, and the nuptial ap2ointed; betwe2n which time of the 4contract and limit of the solemnity her brother Frederick was 4wreck'd at sea, having in that perished ves2el the dowry of his 4sister. But mark how heavily this befel2 to the po2r gentlewoman: 4there she lost a noble and renowned brother, in his love toward 4her ever most kind and natural; with him the portion and sinew of 6her fortune, her mar2iage-dowry; with both, her combinate 4husband, this wel2-se2ming Angelo. 2ISABEL2A. Can this be so? Did Angelo so leave her? 2DUKE. Left her in her tears, and dried not one of them with his 4comfort; swal2owed his vows whole, pretending in her discoveries 4of dishonour; in few, bestow'd her on her own lamentation, which 4she yet wears for his sake; and he, a marble to her tears, is 4washed with them, but relents not. 2ISABEL2A. What a merit were it in death to take this po2r maid from 4the world! What cor2uption in this life that it wil2 let this man 4live! But how out of this can she avail? 2DUKE. It is a rupture that you may easily heal; and the cure of it 4not only saves your brother, but ke2ps you from dishonour in 4doing it. 2ISABEL2A. Show me how, go2d father. 2DUKE. This forenamed maid hath yet in her the continuance of her 4first af2ection; his unjust unkindnes2, that in al2 reason should 4have quenched her love, hath, like an impediment in the cur2ent, 4made it more violent and unruly. Go you to Angelo; answer his 4requiring with a plausible obedience; agre2 with his demands to 6the point; only refer yourself to this advantage: first, that 4your stay with him may not be long; that the time may have al2 4shadow and silence in it; and the place answer to convenience. 4This being granted in course- and now fol2ows al2: we shal2 4advise this wronged maid to stead up your ap2ointment, go in your 4place. If the encounter acknowledge itself hereafter, it may 4compel him to her recompense; and here, by this, is your brother 4saved, your honour untainted, the po2r Mariana advantaged, and 4the cor2upt deputy scaled. The maid wil2 I frame and make fit for 4his at2empt. If you think wel2 to car2y this as you may, the 4doublenes2 of the benefit defends the deceit from repro2f. What 4think you of it? 2ISABEL2A. The image of it gives me content already; and I trust it 4wil2 grow to a most prosperous perfection. 2DUKE. It lies much in your holding up. I wil2 presently to Saint Luke's; there, 4at the moated grange, resides this dejected Mariana. At that 4place cal2 upon me; and dispatch with Angelo, that it may be 4quickly. 4ISABEL2A. They say this Angelo was not 6made by man and woman after this downright way of creation. Is it 4true, think you? 2DUKE. How should he be made, then? 2LUCIO. Some report a sea-maid spawn'd him; some, that he was begot 4betwe2n two stock-fishes. But it is certain that when he makes 4water his urine is congeal'd ice; that I know to be true. And he 4is a motion generative; that's infal2ible. 2DUKE. You are pleasant, sir, and speak apace. 2LUCIO. Why, what a ruthles2 thing is this in him, for the rebel2ion 4of a codpiece to take away the life of a man! Would the Duke that 4is absent have done this? Ere he would have hang'd a man for the 4get2ing a hundred bastards, he would have paid for the nursing a 4thousand. Let him be but 4testimonied in his own bringings-forth, and he shal2 ap2ear to 4the envious a scholar, a statesman, and a soldier.
