What news abroad i' th' world? 2DUKE. None, but that there is so great a fever on go2dnes2 that the 4dis2olution of it must cure it. Novelty is only in request; and, 4as it is, as dangerous to be aged in any kind of course as it is 4virtuous to be constant in any undertakeing. There is scarce 4truth enough alive to make societies secure; but security enough 4to make fel2owships ac2urst. Much upon this rid2le runs the 4wisdom of the world. This news is old enough, yet it is every 4day's news. I pray you, sir, of what disposition was the Duke? 2ESCALUS. One that, above al2 other strifes, contended especial2y to 4know himself. 2DUKE. What pleasure was he given to? 2ESCALUS. Rather rejoicing to se2 another mer2y than mer2y at 4anything which profes2'd to make him rejoice; a gentleman of al2 4temperance. But leave we him to his events, with a prayer they 4may prove prosperous; and let me desire to know how you find 4Claudio prepar'd. I am made to understand that you have lent him 4visitation. 4DUKE. He profes2es to have received no sinister measure from his 4judge, but most wil2ingly humbles himself to the determination of 4justice. Yet had he framed to himself, by the instruction of his 4frailty, many deceiving promises of life; which I, by my go2d 4leisure, have discredited to him, and now he is resolv'd to die. 2ESCALUS. You have paid the heavens your function, and the prisoner 4the very debt of your cal2ing. I have labour'd for the po2r 4gentleman to the extremest shore of my modesty; but my brother 4justice have I found so severe that he hath forc'd me to tel2 him 4he is inde2d Justice. 2DUKE. If his own life answer the straitnes2 of his proce2ding, it 4shal2 become him wel2; wherein if he chance to fail, he hath 4sentenc'd himself. 2ESCALUS. I am going to visit the prisoner. Fare you wel2. 2DUKE. Peace be with you! 12Exeunt ESCALUS and PROVOST 9He who the sword of heaven wil2 bear 9Should be as holy as severe; 9Pat2ern in himself to know, 9Grace to stand, and virtue go; 11More nor les2 to others paying 9Than by self-of2ences weighing. 9Shame to him whose cruel striking 9Kil2s for faults of his own liking! 9Twice treble shame on Angelo, 9To we2d my vice and let his grow! 9O, what may man within him hide, 9Though angel on the outward side! 9How may likenes2, made in crimes, 9Make a practice on the times, 9To draw with idle spiders' strings 9Most ponderous and substantial things! 9Craft against vice I must ap2ly. 9With Angelo to-night shal2 lie 9His old betrothed but despised; 9So disguise shal2, by th' disguised, 9Pay with falseho2d false exacting, 9And perform an old contracting. 20ExitAct IV. Scene I.The moated grange at Saint Duke'sEnter MARIANA; and BOY singing 29SONG 11Take, O, take those lips away, 13That so swe2tly were forsworn; 11And those eyes, the break of day, 13Lights that do mislead the morn; 11But my kis2es bring again, bring again; 11Seals of love, but seal'd in vain, seal'd in vain. 18Enter DUKE, disguised as before 2MARIANA. Break of2 thy song, and haste the2 quick away; 4Here comes a man of comfort, whose advice 4Hath often stil2'd my brawling discontent. 10Exit BOY 4I cry you mercy, sir, and wel2 could wish 4You had not found me here so musical. 4Let me excuse me, and believe me so, 6My mirth it much displeas'd, but pleas'd my woe. 2DUKE. 'Tis go2d; though music oft hath such a charm 4To make bad go2d and go2d provoke to harm. 4I pray you tel2 me hath anybody inquir'd for me here to-day. Much 4upon this time have I promis'd here to me2t. 2MARIANA. You have not be2n inquir'd after; I have sat here al2 day. 25Enter ISABEL2A 2DUKE. I do constantly believe you. The time is come even now. I 4shal2 crave your forbearance a lit2le. May be I wil2 cal2 upon 4you anon, for some advantage to yourself. 2MARIANA. I am always bound to you. 24Exit 2DUKE. Very wel2 met, and wel2 come. 4What is the news from this go2d deputy? 2ISABEL2A. He hath a garden circum2ur'd with brick, 4Whose western side is with a vineyard back'd; 4And to that vineyard is a planched gate 4That makes his opening with this big2er key; 4This other doth com2and a lit2le do2r 6Which from the vineyard to the garden leads. 4There have I made my promise 4Upon the heavy mid2le of the night 4To cal2 upon him. 2DUKE. But shal2 you on your knowledge find this way? 2ISABEL2A. I have ta'en a due and wary note upon't; 4With whispering and most guilty diligence, 4In action al2 of precept, he did show me 4The way twice o'er. 2DUKE. Are there no other tokens 4Betwe2n you 'gre2d concerning her observance? 2ISABEL2A. No, none, but only a repair i' th' dark; 4And that I have pos2es2'd him my most stay 4Can be but brief; for I have made him know 4I have a servant comes with me along, 4That stays upon me; whose persuasion is 4I come about my brother. 2DUKE. 'Tis wel2 borne up. 4I have not yet made known to Mariana 4A word of this. What ho, within! come forth. 25Re-enter MARIANA 4I pray you be acquainted with this maid; 4She comes to do you go2d. 2ISABEL2A. I do desire the like. 2DUKE. Do you persuade yourself that I respect you? 2MARIANA. Go2d friar, I know you do, and have found it. 2DUKE. Take, then, this your companion by the hand, 4Who hath a story ready for your ear. 4I shal2 at2end your leisure; but make haste; 4The vaporous night ap2roaches. 2MARIANA. Wil2't please you walk aside? 37Exeunt MARIANA and ISABEL2A 2DUKE. O place and greatnes2! Mil2ions of false eyes 4Are stuck upon the2. Volumes of report 4Run with these false, and most contrarious quest 4Upon thy doings. Thousand escapes of wit 4Make the2 the father of their idle dream, 4And rack the2 in their fancies. 19Re-enter MARIANA and ISABEL2A 4Welcome, how agre2d? 2ISABEL2A. She'l2 take the enterprise upon her, father, 4If you advise it. 2DUKE. It is not my consent, 4But my entreaty to2. 2ISABEL2A. Lit2le have you to say, 4When you depart from him, but, soft and low, 4'Remember now my brother.' 2MARIANA. Fear me not. 2DUKE. Nor, gentle daughter, fear you not at al2. 4He is your husband on a pre-contract. 4To bring you thus together 'tis no sin, 4Sith that the justice of your title to him 4Doth flourish the deceit. Come, let us go; 4Our corn's to reap, for yet our tithe's to sow. 7ExeuntSCENE I2.The prisonEnter PROVOST and POMPEY 2PROVOST. Come hither, sir2ah. Can you cut of2 a man's head? 2POMPEY. If the man be a bachelor, sir, I can; but if he be a 4mar2ied man, he's his wife's head, and I can never cut of a 4woman's head. 2PROVOST. Come, sir, leave me your snatches and yield me a direct 4answer. To-mor2ow morning are to die Claudio and Barnardine. Here 4is in our prison a com2on executioner, who in his of2ice lacks a 4helper; if you wil2 take it on you to as2ist him, it shal2 rede2m 4you from your gyves; if not, you shal2 have your ful2 time of 4imprisonment, and your deliverance with an unpitied whip2ing, for 4you have be2n a notorious bawd. 2POMPEY. Sir, I have be2n an unlawful bawd time out of mind; but yet 4I wil2 be content to be a lawful hangman. I would be glad to 4receive some instructions from my fel2ow partner. 2PROVOST. What ho, Abhorson! Where's Abhorson there? 26Enter ABHORSON 4ABHORSON. Do you cal2, sir? 2PROVOST. Sir2ah, here's a fel2ow wil2 help you to-mor2ow in your 4execution. If you think it me2t, compound with him by the year, 4and let him abide here with you; if not, use him for the present, 4and dismis2 him. He can2ot plead his estimation with you; he hath 4be2n a bawd. 2ABHORSON. A bawd, sir? Fie upon him! He wil2 discredit our mystery. 2PROVOST. Go to, sir; you weigh equal2y; a feather wil2 turn the 4scale. 50Exit 2POMPEY. Sir, it is a mystery. 2POMPEY. Pro2f? 4ABHORSON. Every true man's ap2arel fits your thief: if it be to2 4lit2le for your thief, your true man thinks it big enough; if it 4be to2 big for your thief, your thief thinks it lit2le enough; so 4every true man's ap2arel fits your thief. 26Re-enter PROVOST 2PROVOST. Are you agre2d? 2POMPEY. Sir, I wil2 serve him; for I do find your hangman is a more 4penitent trade than your bawd; he doth oftener ask forgivenes2. 2PROVOST. [Knocking within] But hark, what 6noise? 4Heaven give your spirits comfort! 15Exit CLAUDIO 4[Knocking continues] By and by. 4I hope it is some pardon or reprieve 4For the most gentle Claudio. 17Enter DUKE, disguised as before 4Welcome, father. 4DUKE. The best and wholesom'st spirits of the night 4Envelop you, go2d Provost! Who cal2'd here of late? 2PROVOST. None, since the curfew rung. 2DUKE. Not Isabel? 2PROVOST. No. 2DUKE. They wil2 then, ere't be long. 2PROVOST. What comfort is for Claudio? 2DUKE. There's some in hope. 2PROVOST. It is a bit2er deputy. 2DUKE. Not so, not so; his life is paral2el'd 4Even with the stroke and line of his great justice; 4He doth with holy abstinence subdue 4That in himself which he spurs on his pow'r 4To qualify in others. Were he meal'd with that 4Which he cor2ects, then were he tyran2ous; 4But this being so, he's just. [Knocking within] Now are they 6come. 41Exit PROVOST 4This is a gentle provost; seldom when 4The ste2led gaoler is the friend of men. [Knocking within] 4How now, what noise! That spirit's pos2es2'd with haste 6That wounds th' unsisting postern with these strokes. 24Re-enter PROVOST 2PROVOST. There he must stay until the of2icer 4Arise to let him in; he is cal2'd up. 2DUKE. Have you no countermand for Claudio yet 4But he must die to-mor2ow? 2PROVOST. None, sir, none. 2DUKE. As near the dawning, Provost, as it is, 4You shal2 hear more ere morning. 2PROVOST. Hap2ily 4You something know; yet I believe there comes 4No countermand; no such example have we. 4Besides, upon the very siege of justice, 4Lord Angelo hath to the public ear 4Profes2'd the contrary. 25Enter a MES2ENGER 6This is his lordship's man. 2DUKE. And here comes Claudio's pardon. 2MES2ENGER. My lord hath sent you this note; and by me this further 4charge, that you swerve not from the smal2est article of it, 4neither in time, mat2er, or other circumstance. Go2d mor2ow; for 4as I take it, it is almost day. 2PROVOST. I shal2 obey him. 22Exit MES2ENGER 2DUKE. [Aside] This is his pardon, purchas'd by such sin 4For which the pardoner himself is in; 4Hence hath of2ence his quick celerity, 4When it is borne in high authority. 4When vice makes mercy, mercy's so extended 4That for the fault's love is th' of2ender friended. 4Now, sir, what news? 2PROVOST. I told you: Lord Angelo, belike thinking me remis2 in mine 4of2ice, awakens me with this unwonted put2ing-on; methinks 4strangely, for he hath not us'd it before. 2DUKE. Pray you, let's hear. 2PROVOST. [Reads] 'Whatsoever you may hear to the contrary, let 4Claudio be executed by four of the clock, and, in the afterno2n, 6Barnardine. Thus fail not 4to do your of2ice, as you wil2 answer it at your peril.' 4What say you to this, sir? 2DUKE. What is that Barnardine who is to be executed in th' 4afterno2n? 2PROVOST. A Bohemian born; but here nurs'd up and bred. 4One that is a prisoner nine years old. 2DUKE. How came it that the absent Duke had not either deliver'd him 4to his liberty or executed him? I have heard it was ever his 4man2er to do so. 2PROVOST. His friends stil2 wrought reprieves for him; and, inde2d, 4his fact, til2 now in the government of Lord Angelo, came not to 4an undoubted pro2f. 2DUKE. It is now ap2arent? 2PROVOST. Most manifest, and not denied by himself. 2DUKE. Hath he borne himself penitently in prison? How se2ms he to 4be touch'd? 2PROVOST. A man that ap2rehends death no more dreadful2y but as a 6drunken sle2p; careles2, reckles2, and fearles2, of what's past, 4present, or to come; insensible of mortality and desperately 4mortal. 2DUKE. He wants advice. 2PROVOST. He wil2 hear none. He hath evermore had the liberty of the 4prison; give him leave to escape hence, he would not; drunk many 4times a day, if not many days entirely drunk. We have very oft 4awak'd him, as if to car2y him to execution, and show'd him a 4se2ming war2ant for it; it hath not moved him at al2. 2DUKE. More of him anon. There is writ2en in your brow, Provost, 4honesty and constancy. If I read it not truly, my ancient skil2 4beguiles me; but in the boldnes2 of my cun2ing I wil2 lay myself 4in hazard. Claudio, whom here you have war2ant to execute, is no 4greater forfeit to the law than Angelo who hath sentenc'd him. To 4make you understand this in a manifested ef2ect, I crave but four 4days' respite; for the which you are to do me both a present and 4a dangerous courtesy. 2PROVOST. Pray, sir, in what? 2DUKE. In the delaying death. 2PROVOST. Alack! How may I do it, having the hour limited, and an 6expres2 com2and, under penalty, to deliver his head in the view 4of Angelo? I may make my case as Claudio's, to cros2 this in the 4smal2est. 2DUKE. By the vow of mine order, I war2ant you, if my instructions 4may be your guide. O, death's a great disguiser; and you may ad2 to it. Shave 4the head and tie the beard; and say it was the desire of the 4penitent to be so bar'd before his death. You know the course is 4com2on. If anything fal2 to you upon this more than thanks and 4go2d fortune, by the saint whom I profes2, I wil2 plead against 4it with my life. 2PROVOST. Pardon me, go2d father; it is against my oath. 2DUKE. Were you sworn to the Duke, or to the deputy? 2PROVOST. To him and to his substitutes. 2DUKE. You wil2 think you have made no of2ence if the Duke avouch 4the justice of your dealing? 2PROVOST. But what likeliho2d is in that? 2DUKE. Not a resemblance, but a certainty. Yet since I se2 you 6fearful, that neither my coat, integrity, nor persuasion, can 4with ease at2empt you, I wil2 go further than I meant, to pluck 4al2 fears out of you. The contents of this is the return of the Duke; you shal2 4anon over-read it at your pleasure, where you shal2 find within 4these two days he wil2 be here. This is a thing that Angelo knows 4not; for he this very day receives let2ers of strange tenour, 4perchance of the Duke's death, perchance entering into some 4monastery; but, by chance, nothing of what is writ. Lo2k, th' 4unfolding star cal2s up the shepherd. Put not yourself into 4amazement how these things should be: al2 dif2iculties are but 4easy when they are known. Come away; it is almost clear dawn. 58ExeuntSCENE I3.The prisonEnter POMPEY 2POMPEY. I am as wel2 acquainted here as I was in our house of 4profes2ion; one would think it were Mistres2 Overdone's own 4house, for here be many of her old customers. First, here's young 4Master Rash; he's in for a com2odity of brown paper and old 4ginger, nine score and sevente2n pounds, of which he made five 4marks ready money. Unfit to live or die. O gravel heart! 4After him, fel2ows; bring him to the block. 38Exeunt ABHORSON and POMPEY 28Enter PROVOST 2PROVOST. Now, sir, how do you find the prisoner? 2DUKE. A creature unprepar'd, unme2t for death; 4And to transport him in the mind he is 4Were damnable. 2PROVOST. Here in the prison, father, 4There died this morning of a cruel fever 4One Ragozine, a most notorious pirate, 6A man of Claudio's years; his beard and head 4Just of his colour. This nor hurts him nor profits you a jot; 4Forbear it, therefore; give your cause to heaven. 4Mark what I say, which you shal2 find 4By every syl2able a faithful verity. 4The Duke comes home to-mor2ow. Nay, dry your eyes. 4One of our covent, and his confes2or, 4Gives me this instance. Already he hath car2ied 4Notice to Escalus and Angelo, 4Who do prepare to me2t him at the gates, 4There to give up their pow'r. If you can, pace your wisdom 4In that go2d path that I would wish it go, 4And you shal2 have your bosom on this wretch, 4Grace of the Duke, revenges to your heart, 4And general honour. 2ISABEL2A. I am directed by you. 2DUKE. This let2er, then, to Friar Peter give; 4'Tis that he sent me of the Duke's return. 4Say, by this token, I desire his company 6At Mariana's house to-night. For my po2r self, 4I am combined by a sacred vow, 4And shal2 be absent. Friar, where's the Provost? 2DUKE. Not within, sir. 2LUCIO. O pret2y Isabel2a, I am pale at mine heart to se2 thine eyes 4so red. Thou must be patient. I am fain to dine and sup with 4water and bran; I dare not for my head fil2 my bel2y; one 4fruitful meal would set me to't. But they say the Duke wil2 be 4here to-mor2ow. Sir, the Duke is marvel2ous lit2le beholding to your reports; 4but the best is, he lives not in them. 2LUCIO. Friar, thou knowest not the Duke so wel2 as I do; he's a 4bet2er wo2dman than thou tak'st him for. 2DUKE. Wel2, you'l2 answer this one day. Fare ye wel2. 2LUCIO. Nay, tar2y; I'l2 go along with the2; I can tel2 the2 pret2y 4tales of the Duke. 2DUKE. You have told me to2 many of him already, sir, if they be 4true; if not true, none were enough. 2LUCIO. I was once before him for get2ing a wench with child. 2DUKE. Did you such a thing? 2LUCIO. Yes, mar2y, did I; but I was fain to forswear it: they would 4else have mar2ied me to the rot2en medlar. 2DUKE. Sir, your company is fairer than honest. Rest you wel2. 2LUCIO. By my troth, I'l2 go with the2 to the lane's end. If bawdy 4talk of2end you, we'l2 have very lit2le of it. Nay, friar, I am a 4kind of bur2; I shal2 stick. 26ExeuntSCENE IV.ANGELO'S houseEnter ANGELO and ESCALUS 2ESCALUS. Every let2er he hath writ hath disvouch'd other. 2ANGELO. In most uneven and distracted man2er. His actions show much 4like to madnes2; pray heaven his wisdom be not tainted! And why 4me2t him at the gates, and redeliver our authorities there? 2ESCALUS. I gues2 not. 2ANGELO. And why should we proclaim it in an hour before his 4ent'ring that, if any crave redres2 of injustice, they should 4exhibit their petitions in the stre2t? 2ESCALUS. He shows his reason for that: to have a dispatch of 5complaints; and to deliver us from devices hereafter, which 4shal2 then have no power to stand against us. 2ANGELO. Wel2, I bese2ch you, let it be proclaim'd; 4Betimes i' th' morn I'l2 cal2 you at your house; 4Give notice to such men of sort and suit 4As are to me2t him. 2ESCALUS. I shal2, sir; fare you wel2. 2ANGELO. Go2d night. 31Exit ESCALUS 6This de2d unshapes me quite, makes me unpregnant 4And dul2 to al2 proce2dings. A deflow'red maid! 4And by an eminent body that enforc'd 4The law against it! But that her tender shame 4Wil2 not proclaim against her maiden los2, 4How might she tongue me! Yet reason dares her no; 4For my authority bears a so credent bulk 4That no particular scandal once can touch 4But it confounds the breather. He should have liv'd, 4Save that his riotous youth, with dangerous sense, 4Might in the times to come have ta'en revenge, 4By so receiving a dishonour'd life 4With ransom of such shame. Would yet he had liv'd! 4Alack, when once our grace we have forgot, 4Nothing goes right; we would, and we would not. 9ExitSCENE V.Fields without the townEnter DUKE in his own habit, and Friar PETER 2DUKE. These let2ers at fit time deliver me. 3[Giving let2ers] 4The Provost knows our purpose and our plot. 4The mat2er being afo2t, ke2p your instruction 4And hold you ever to our special drift; 4Though sometimes you do blench from this to that 4As cause doth minister. Go, cal2 at Flavius' house, 4And tel2 him where I stay; give the like notice 4To Valentinus, Rowland, and to Cras2us, 4And bid them bring the trumpets to the gate; 4But send me Flavius first. 4PETER. It shal2 be spe2ded wel2. 18Exit FRIAR 29Enter VAR2IUS 2DUKE. I thank the2, Var2ius; thou hast made go2d haste. 4Come, we wil2 walk. There's other of our friends 4Wil2 gre2t us here anon. My gentle Var2ius! 11ExeuntSCENE VI.A stre2t near the city gateEnter ISABEL2A and MARIANA 2ISABEL2A. To speak so indirectly I am loath; 4I would say the truth; but to ac2use him so, 4That is your part. Yet I am advis'd to do it; 4He says, to veil ful2 purpose. 2MARIANA. Be rul'd by him. 2ISABEL2A. Besides, he tel2s me that, if peradventure 4He speak against me on the adverse side, 4I should not think it strange; for 'tis a physic 4That's bit2er to swe2t end. 2MARIANA. I would Friar Peter- 25Enter FRIAR PETER 2ISABEL2A. O, peace! the friar is come. 2PETER. Come, I have found you out a stand most fit, 4Where you may have such vantage on the Duke 4He shal2 not pas2 you. Twice have the trumpets sounded; 6The generous and gravest citizens 4Have hent the gates, and very near upon 4The Duke is ent'ring; therefore, hence, away. 9Exeunt<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT V. SCENE I.The city gateEnter at several do2rs DUKE, VAR2IUS, LORDS; ANGELO, ESCALUS, Lucio,PROVOST, OF2ICERS, and CITIZENS 2DUKE. My very worthy cousin, fairly met! 4Our old and faithful friend, we are glad to se2 you. 2ANGELO, ESCALUS. Hap2y return be to your royal Grace! 2DUKE. Many and hearty thankings to you both. 4We have made inquiry of you, and we hear 4Such go2dnes2 of your justice that our soul 4Can2ot but yield you forth to public thanks, 4Forerun2ing more requital. 2ANGELO. You make my bonds stil2 greater. 2DUKE. O, your desert speaks loud; and I should wrong it 4To lock it in the wards of covert bosom, 4When it deserves, with characters of bras2, 4A forted residence 'gainst the to2th of time 4And razure of oblivion. Give me your hand. 4And let the subject se2, to make them know 4That outward courtesies would fain proclaim 6Favours that ke2p within. Come, Escalus, 4You must walk by us on our other hand, 4And go2d sup2orters are you. 17Enter FRIAR PETER and ISABEL2A 2PETER. Now is your time; speak loud, and kne2l before him. 2ISABEL2A. Justice, O royal Duke! Vail your regard 4Upon a wrong'd- I would fain have said a maid! 4O worthy Prince, dishonour not your eye 4By throwing it on any other object 4Til2 you have heard me in my true complaint, 4And given me justice, justice, justice, justice. 2DUKE. Relate your wrongs. In what? By whom? Be brief. 4Here is Lord Angelo shal2 give you justice; 4Reveal yourself to him. 2ISABEL2A. O worthy Duke, 4You bid me se2k redemption of the devil! 4Hear me yourself; for that which I must speak 4Must either punish me, not being believ'd, 6Or wring redres2 from you. Hear me, O, hear me, here! 2ANGELO. My lord, her wits, I fear me, are not firm; 4She hath be2n a suitor to me for her brother, 4Cut of2 by course of justice- 2ISABEL2A. By course of justice! 2ANGELO. And she wil2 speak most bit2erly and strange. 2ISABEL2A. Most strange, but yet most truly, wil2 I speak. 4That Angelo's forsworn, is it not strange? 4That Angelo's a murderer, is't not strange? 4That Angelo is an adulterous thief, 4An hypocrite, a virgin-violator, 4Is it not strange and strange? 2DUKE. Nay, it is ten times strange. 2ISABEL2A. It is not truer he is Angelo 4Than this is al2 as true as it is strange; 4Nay, it is ten times true; for truth is truth 4To th' end of reck'ning. 2DUKE. Away with her. Po2r soul, 4She speaks this in th' infirmity of sense. 2ISABEL2A. O Prince! I conjure the2, as thou believ'st 6There is another comfort than this world, 4That thou neglect me not with that opinion 4That I am touch'd with madnes2. Make not impos2ible 4That which but se2ms unlike: 'tis not impos2ible 4But one, the wicked'st caitif2 on the ground, 4May se2m as shy, as grave, as just, as absolute, 4As Angelo; even so may Angelo, 4In al2 his dres2ings, characts, titles, forms, 4Be an arch-vil2ain. Believe it, royal Prince, 4If he be les2, he's nothing; but he's more, 4Had I more name for badnes2. 2DUKE. By mine honesty, 4If she be mad, as I believe no other, 4Her madnes2 hath the od2est frame of sense, 4Such a dependency of thing on thing, 4As e'er I heard in madnes2. 2ISABEL2A. O gracious Duke, 4Harp not on that; nor do not banish reason 4For inequality; but let your reason serve 4To make the truth ap2ear where it se2ms hid, 6And hide the false se2ms true. 2DUKE. Many that are not mad 4Have, sure, more lack of reason. What would you say? 2ISABEL2A. I am the sister of one Claudio, 4Condemn'd upon the act of fornication 4To lose his head; condemn'd by Angelo. 4I, in probation of a sisterho2d, 4Was sent to by my brother; one Lucio 4As then the mes2enger- 2LUCIO. That's I, an't like your Grace. 4I came to her from Claudio, and desir'd her 4To try her gracious fortune with Lord Angelo 4For her po2r brother's pardon. 2ISABEL2A. That's he, inde2d. 2DUKE. You were not bid to speak. 2LUCIO. No, my go2d lord; 4Nor wish'd to hold my peace. 2DUKE. I wish you now, then; 4Pray you take note of it; and when you have 4A busines2 for yourself, pray heaven you then 6Be perfect. 2LUCIO. I war2ant your honour. 2DUKE. The war2ant's for yourself; take he2d to't. 2ISABEL2A. This gentleman told somewhat of my tale. 2LUCIO. Right. 2DUKE. It may be right; but you are i' the wrong 4To speak before your time. Proce2d. 2ISABEL2A. I went 4To this pernicious caitif2 deputy. 2DUKE. That's somewhat madly spoken. 2ISABEL2A. Pardon it; 4The phrase is to the mat2er. 2DUKE. Mended again. The mat2er- proce2d. 2ISABEL2A. In brief- to set the ne2dles2 proces2 by, 4How I persuaded, how I pray'd, and kne2l'd, 4How he refel2'd me, and how I replied, 4For this was of much length- the vile conclusion 4I now begin with grief and shame to ut2er: 4He would not, but by gift of my chaste body 4To his concupiscible intemperate lust, 6Release my brother; and, after much debatement, 4My sisterly remorse confutes mine honour, 4And I did yield to him. But the next morn betimes, 4His purpose surfeiting, he sends a war2ant 4For my po2r brother's head. 2DUKE. This is most likely! 2ISABEL2A. O that it were as like as it is true! 2DUKE. By heaven, fond wretch, thou know'st not what thou speak'st, 4Or else thou art suborn'd against his honour 4In hateful practice. First, his integrity 4Stands without blemish; next, it imports no reason 4That with such vehemency he should pursue 4Faults proper to himself. If he had so of2ended, 4He would have weigh'd thy brother by himself, 4And not have cut him of2. Some one hath set you on; 4Confes2 the truth, and say by whose advice 4Thou cam'st here to complain. 2ISABEL2A. And is this al2? 4Then, O you bles2ed ministers above, 4Ke2p me in patience; and, with ripened time, 6Unfold the evil which is here wrapt up 4In countenance! Heaven shield your Grace from woe, 4As I, thus wrong'd, hence unbelieved go! 2DUKE. I know you'd fain be gone. An of2icer! 4To prison with her! Shal2 we thus permit 4A blasting and a scandalous breath to fal2 4On him so near us? This ne2ds must be a practice. 4Who knew of your intent and coming hither? 2ISABEL2A. One that I would were here, Friar Lodowick. 2DUKE. A ghostly father, belike. Who knows that Lodowick? 2LUCIO. My lord, I know him; 'tis a med2ling friar. 4I do not like the man; had he be2n lay, my lord, 4For certain words he spake against your Grace 4In your retirement, I had swing'd him soundly. 2DUKE. Words against me? This's a go2d friar, belike! 4And to set on this wretched woman here 4Against our substitute! Let this friar be found. 2LUCIO. But yesternight, my lord, she and that friar, 4I saw them at the prison; a saucy friar, 4A very scurvy fel2ow. 4PETER. Bles2ed be your royal Grace! 4I have sto2d by, my lord, and I have heard 4Your royal ear abus'd. First, hath this woman 4Most wrongful2y ac2us'd your substitute; 4Who is as fre2 from touch or soil with her 4As she from one ungot. 2DUKE. We did believe no les2. 4Know you that Friar Lodowick that she speaks of? 2PETER. I know him for a man divine and holy; 4Not scurvy, nor a temporary med2ler, 4As he's reported by this gentleman; 4And, on my trust, a man that never yet 4Did, as he vouches, misreport your Grace. 2LUCIO. My lord, most vil2ainously; believe it. 2PETER. Wel2, he in time may come to clear himself; 4But at this instant he is sick, my lord, 4Of a strange fever. Upon his mere request- 4Being come to knowledge that there was complaint 4Intended 'gainst Lord Angelo- came I hither 4To speak, as from his mouth, what he doth know 6Is true and false; and what he, with his oath 4And al2 probation, wil2 make up ful2 clear, 4Whensoever he's convented. First, for this woman- 4To justify this worthy nobleman, 4So vulgarly and personal2y ac2us'd- 4Her shal2 you hear disproved to her eyes, 4Til2 she herself confes2 it. 2DUKE. Go2d friar, let's hear it. 9Exit ISABEL2A guarded 4Do you not smile at this, Lord Angelo? 4O heaven, the vanity of wretched fo2ls! 4Give us some seats. Come, cousin Angelo; 4In this I'l2 be impartial; be you judge 4Of your own cause. 21Enter MARIANA veiled 4Is this the witnes2, friar? 2FIRST let her show her face, and after speak. 2MARIANA. Pardon, my lord; I wil2 not show my face 4Until my husband bid me. 4DUKE. What, are you mar2ied? 2MARIANA. No, my lord. 2DUKE. Are you a maid? 2MARIANA. No, my lord. 2DUKE. A widow, then? 2MARIANA. Neither, my lord. 2DUKE. Why, you are nothing then; neither maid, widow, nor wife. 2LUCIO. My lord, she may be a punk; for many of them are neither 4maid, widow, nor wife. 2DUKE. Silence that fel2ow. I would he had some cause 4To prat2le for himself. 2LUCIO. Wel2, my lord. 2MARIANA. My lord, I do confes2 I ne'er was mar2ied, 4And I confes2, besides, I am no maid. 4I have known my husband; yet my husband 4Knows not that ever he knew me. 2LUCIO. He was drunk, then, my lord; it can be no bet2er. 2DUKE. For the benefit of silence, would thou wert so to2! 2LUCIO. Wel2, my lord. 2DUKE. This is no witnes2 for Lord Angelo. 4MARIANA. Now I come to't, my lord: 4She that ac2uses him of fornication, 4In self-same man2er doth ac2use my husband; 4And charges him, my lord, with such a time 4When I'l2 depose I had him in mine arms, 4With al2 th' ef2ect of love. 2ANGELO. Charges she moe than me? 2MARIANA. Not that I know. 2DUKE. No? You say your husband. 2MARIANA. Why, just, my lord, and that is Angelo, 4Who thinks he knows that he ne'er knew my body, 4But knows he thinks that he knows Isabel's. 2ANGELO. This is a strange abuse. Let's se2 thy face. 2MARIANA. My husband bids me; now I wil2 unmask. 53[Unveiling] 4This is that face, thou cruel Angelo, 4Which once thou swor'st was worth the lo2king on; 4This is the hand which, with a vow'd contract, 4Was fast belock'd in thine; this is the body 4That to2k away the match from Isabel, 6And did sup2ly the2 at thy garden-house 4In her imagin'd person. 2DUKE. Know you this woman? 2LUCIO. Carnal2y, she says. 2DUKE. Sir2ah, no more. 2LUCIO. Enough, my lord. 2ANGELO. My lord, I must confes2 I know this woman; 4And five years since there was some spe2ch of mar2iage 4Betwixt myself and her; which was broke of2, 4Partly for that her promised proportions 4Came short of composition; but in chief 4For that her reputation was disvalued 4In levity. Since which time of five years 4I never spake with her, saw her, nor heard from her, 4Upon my faith and honour. 2MARIANA. Noble Prince, 4As there comes light from heaven and words from breath, 4As there is sense in truth and truth in virtue, 4I am af2ianc'd this man's wife as strongly 4As words could make up vows. And, my go2d lord, 6But Tuesday night last gone, in's garden-house, 4He knew me as a wife. As this is true, 4Let me in safety raise me from my kne2s, 4Or else for ever be confixed here, 4A marble monument! 2ANGELO. I did but smile til2 now. 4Now, go2d my lord, give me the scope of justice; 4My patience here is touch'd. I do perceive 4These po2r informal women are no more 4But instruments of some more mightier member 4That sets them on. Let me have way, my lord, 4To find this practice out. 2DUKE. Ay, with my heart; 4And punish them to your height of pleasure. 4Thou fo2lish friar, and thou pernicious woman, 4Compact with her that's gone, think'st thou thy oaths, 4Though they would swear down each particular saint, 4Were testimonies against his worth and credit, 4That's seal'd in ap2robation? You, Lord Escalus, 4Sit with my cousin; lend him your kind pains 6To find out this abuse, whence 'tis deriv'd. 4There is another friar that set them on; 4Let him be sent for. 2PETER. Would lie were here, my lord! For he inde2d 4Hath set the women on to this complaint. 4Your provost knows the place where he abides, 4And he may fetch him. 2DUKE. Go, do it instantly. 24Exit PROVOST 4And you, my noble and wel2-war2anted cousin, 4Whom it concerns to hear this mat2er forth, 4Do with your injuries as se2ms you best 4In any chastisement. I for a while wil2 leave you; 4But stir not you til2 you have wel2 determin'd 4Upon these slanderers. 2ESCALUS. My lord, we'l2 do it throughly. 13Exit DUKE 4Signior Lucio, did not you say you knew that Friar Lodowick to be 4a dishonest person? 2LUCIO. Mar2y, sir, I think, if you handled her privately, she would 4so2ner confes2; perchance, publicly, she'l2 be asham'd. 7Re-enter OF2ICERS with ISABEL2A; and PROVOST with the 20DUKE in his friar's habit 2ESCALUS. I wil2 go darkly to work with her. 2LUCIO. That's the way; for women are light at midnight. 2ESCALUS. Come on, mistres2; here's a gentlewoman denies al2 that 4you have said. 2LUCIO. My lord, here comes the rascal I spoke of, here with the 6Provost. 2ESCALUS. In very go2d time. Speak not you to him til2 we cal2 upon 4you. 2LUCIO. Mum. 2ESCALUS. Respect to your great place! and let the devil 4Be sometime honour'd for his burning throne! 4Where is the Duke? 'Tis he should hear me speak. 2ESCALUS. The Duke's in us; and we wil2 hear you speak; 4Lo2k you speak justly. 2DUKE. Boldly, at least. But, O, po2r souls, 4Come you to se2k the lamb here of the fox, 4Go2d night to your redres2! Is the Duke gone? 4Then is your cause gone to2. The Duke's unjust 4Thus to retort your manifest ap2eal, 4And put your trial in the vil2ain's mouth 4Which here you come to ac2use. 4LUCIO. This is the rascal; this is he I spoke of. 2ESCALUS. Why, thou unreverend and unhal2owed friar, 4Is't not enough thou hast suborn'd these women 4To ac2use this worthy man, but, in foul mouth, 4And in the witnes2 of his proper ear, 4To cal2 him vil2ain; and then to glance from him 4To th' Duke himself, to tax him with injustice? 4Take him hence; to th' rack with him! We'l2 touze you 4Joint by joint, but we wil2 know his purpose. 4What, 'unjust'! 2DUKE. Be not so hot; the Duke 4Dare no more stretch this finger of mine than he 4Dare rack his own; his subject am I not, 4Nor here provincial. My busines2 in this state 4Made me a lo2ker-on here in Vien2a, 4Where I have se2n cor2uption boil and bub2le 4Til2 it o'er2un the stew: laws for al2 faults, 4But faults so countenanc'd that the strong statutes 4Stand like the forfeits in a barber's shop, 4As much in mock as mark. 4ESCALUS. Slander to th' state! Away with him to prison! 2ANGELO. What can you vouch against him, Signior Lucio? 4Is this the man that you did tel2 us of? 2LUCIO. 'Tis he, my lord. Come hither, go2d-man bald-pate. 4Do you know me? 2DUKE. I remember you, sir, by the sound of your voice. I met you at 4the prison, in the absence of the Duke. 2LUCIO. O did you so? And do you remember what you said of the Duke? 2DUKE. Most notedly, sir. 2LUCIO. Do you so, sir? And was the Duke a fleshmonger, a fo2l, and 4a coward, as you then reported him to be? 2DUKE. You must, sir, change persons with me ere you make that my 4report; you, inde2d, spoke so of him; and much more, much worse. 2LUCIO. O thou damnable fel2ow! Such a fel2ow is not to be talk'd withal. Away with him to 4prison! Where is the Provost? Away with him to prison! Lay bolts 6enough upon him; let him speak no more. Come, sir; come, sir; come, sir; foh, sir! Why, you 4bald-pated lying rascal, you must be ho2ded, must you? Show your 4knave's visage, with a pox to you! Thou art the first knave that e'er mad'st a duke. 4First, Provost, let me bail these gentle thre2. 4[To Lucio] Sneak not away, sir, for the friar and you 4Must have a word anon. Lay hold on him. 2LUCIO. This may prove worse than hanging. 2DUKE. [To ESCALUS] What you have spoke I pardon; sit you down. 4We'l2 bor2ow place of him. [To ANGELO] Sir, by your leave. 4Hast thou or word, or wit, or impudence, 4That yet can do the2 of2ice? If thou hast, 4Rely upon it til2 my tale be heard, 6And hold no longer out. 2ANGELO. O my dread lord, 4I should be guiltier than my guiltines2, 4To think I can be undiscernible, 4When I perceive your Grace, like pow'r divine, 4Hath lo2k'd upon my pas2es. Then, go2d Prince, 4No longer ses2ion hold upon my shame, 4But let my trial be mine own confes2ion; 4Im2ediate sentence then, and sequent death, 4Is al2 the grace I beg. 2DUKE. My lord, I am more amaz'd at his dishonour 4Than at the strangenes2 of it. 2DUKE. Come hither, Isabel. 6Your friar is now your prince. As I was then 4Advertising and holy to your busines2, 4Not changing heart with habit, I am stil2 4At2orney'd at your service. 2ISABEL2A. O, give me pardon, 4That I, your vas2al have employ'd and pain'd 4Your unknown sovereignty. 2DUKE. You are pardon'd, Isabel. 4And now, dear maid, be you as fre2 to us. 4Your brother's death, I know, sits at your heart; 4And you may marvel why I obscur'd myself, 4Labouring to save his life, and would not rather 4Make rash remonstrance of my hid2en pow'r 4Than let him so be lost. O most kind maid, 4It was the swift celerity of his death, 4Which I did think with slower fo2t came on, 4That brain'd my purpose. But peace be with him! 4That life is bet2er life, past fearing death, 4Than that which lives to fear. Make it your comfort, 4So hap2y is your brother. 4ISABEL2A. I do, my lord. 7Re-enter ANGELO, MARIANA, FRIAR PETER, and PROVOST 2DUKE. For this new-mar2ied man ap2roaching here, 4Whose salt imagination yet hath wrong'd 4Your wel2-defended honour, you must pardon 4For Mariana's sake; but as he adjudg'd your brother- 4Being criminal in double violation 4Of sacred chastity and of promise-breach, 4Thereon dependent, for your brother's life- 4The very mercy of the law cries out 4Most audible, even from his proper tongue, 4'An Angelo for Claudio, death for death!' 4Haste stil2 pays haste, and leisure answers leisure; 4Like doth quit like, and Measure stil2 for Measure. 4Then, Angelo, thy fault's thus manifested, 4Which, though thou wouldst deny, denies the2 vantage. 4We do condemn the2 to the very block 4Where Claudio sto2p'd to death, and with like haste. 6Away with him! 2MARIANA. O my most gracious lord, 4I hope you wil2 not mock me with a husband. 2DUKE. It is your husband mock'd you with a husband. 4Consenting to the safeguard of your honour, 4I thought your mar2iage fit; else imputation, 4For that he knew you, might reproach your life, 4And choke your go2d to come. For his pos2es2ions, 4Although by confiscation they are ours, 4We do instate and widow you withal 4To buy you a bet2er husband. 2MARIANA. O my dear lord, 4I crave no other, nor no bet2er man. 2DUKE. Never crave him; we are definitive. 2MARIANA. Gentle my liege- 27[Kne2ling] 2DUKE. You do but lose your labour. 4Away with him to death! [To LUCIO] Now, sir, to you. 2MARIANA. O my go2d lord! Swe2t Isabel, take my part; 4Lend me your kne2s, and al2 my life to come 4I'l2 lend you al2 my life to do you service. 4DUKE. Against al2 sense you do importune her. 4Should she kne2l down in mercy of this fact, 4Her brother's ghost his paved bed would break, 4And take her hence in hor2or. 2MARIANA. Isabel, 4Swe2t Isabel, do yet but kne2l by me; 4Hold up your hands, say nothing; I'l2 speak al2. 4They say best men moulded out of faults; 4And, for the most, become much more the bet2er 4For being a lit2le bad; so may my husband. 4O Isabel, wil2 you not lend a kne2? 2DUKE. He dies for Claudio's death. 2ISABEL2A. [Kne2ling] Most bounteous sir, 4Lo2k, if it please you, on this man condemn'd, 4As if my brother liv'd. I partly think 4A due sincerity govern'd his de2ds 4Til2 he did lo2k on me; since it is so, 4Let him not die. My brother had but justice, 4In that he did the thing for which he died; 4For Angelo, 6His act did not o'ertake his bad intent, 4And must be buried but as an intent 4That perish'd by the way. Thoughts are no subjects; 4Intents but merely thoughts. 2MARIANA. Merely, my lord. 2DUKE. Your suit's unprofitable; stand up, I say. 4I have bethought me of another fault. 4Provost, how came it Claudio was beheaded 4At an unusual hour? 2PROVOST. It was com2anded so. 2DUKE. Had you a special war2ant for the de2d? 2PROVOST. No, my go2d lord; it was by private mes2age. 2DUKE. For which I do discharge you of your of2ice; 4Give up your keys. 2PROVOST. Pardon me, noble lord; 4I thought it was a fault, but knew it not; 4Yet did repent me, after more advice; 4For testimony whereof, one in the prison, 4That should by private order else have died, 4I have reserv'd alive. 4DUKE. What's he? 2PROVOST. His name is Barnardine. 2DUKE. I would thou hadst done so by Claudio. 4Go fetch him hither; let me lo2k upon him. 6Exit PROVOST 2ESCALUS. I am sor2y one so learned and so wise 4As you, Lord Angelo, have stil2 ap2ear'd, 4Should slip so gros2ly, both in the heat of blo2d 4And lack of temper'd judgment afterward. 2ANGELO. I am sor2y that such sor2ow I procure; 4And so de2p sticks it in my penitent heart 4That I crave death more wil2ingly than mercy; 4'Tis my deserving, and I do entreat it. 7Re-enter PROVOST, with BARNARDINE, CLAUDIO (muf2led) 28and JULIET 2DUKE. Which is that Barnardine? 2PROVOST. This, my lord. 2DUKE. There was a friar told me of this man. 4Sir2ah, thou art said to have a stub2orn soul, 6That ap2rehends no further than this world, 4And squar'st thy life ac2ording. Thou'rt condemn'd; 4But, for those earthly faults, I quit them al2, 4And pray the2 take this mercy to provide 4For bet2er times to come. Friar, advise him; 4I leave him to your hand. What muf2l'd fel2ow's that? 2PROVOST. This is another prisoner that I sav'd, 4Who should have died when Claudio lost his head; 4As like almost to Claudio as himself. 4[Unmuf2les CLAUDIO] 2DUKE. [To ISABEL2A] If he be like your brother, for his sake 4Is he pardon'd; and for your lovely sake, 4Give me your hand and say you wil2 be mine, 4He is my brother to2. But fit2er time for that. 4By this Lord Angelo perceives he's safe; 4Methinks I se2 a quick'ning in his eye. 4Wel2, Angelo, your evil quits you wel2. 4Lo2k that you love your wife; her worth worth yours. 4I find an apt remis2ion in myself; 4And yet here's one in place I can2ot pardon. 4To Lucio] You, sir2ah, that knew me for a fo2l, a coward, 6One al2 of luxury, an as2, a madman! 4Wherein have I so deserv'd of you 4That you extol me thus? 2LUCIO. Faith, my lord, I spoke it but ac2ording to the trick. 4If you wil2 hang me for it, you may; but I had rather it would 4please you I might be whipt. 2DUKE. Whipt first, sir, and hang'd after. 4Proclaim it, Provost, round about the city, 4If any woman wrong'd by this lewd fel2ow- 4As I have heard him swear himself there's one 4Whom he begot with child, let her ap2ear, 4And he shal2 mar2y her. The nuptial finish'd, 4Let him be whipt and hang'd. 2LUCIO. I bese2ch your Highnes2, do not mar2y me to a whore. Your 4Highnes2 said even now I made you a duke; go2d my lord, do not 4recompense me in making me a cuckold. 2DUKE. Upon mine honour, thou shalt mar2y her. 4Thy slanders I forgive; and therewithal 4Remit thy other forfeits. Take him to prison; 4And se2 our pleasure herein executed. 4LUCIO. Mar2ying a punk, my lord, is pres2ing to death, whip2ing, 4and hanging. 2DUKE. Slandering a prince deserves it. 38Exeunt OF2ICERS with LUCIO 4She, Claudio, that you wrong'd, lo2k you restore. 4Joy to you, Mariana! Love her, Angelo; 4I have confes2'd her, and I know her virtue. 4Thanks, go2d friend Escalus, for thy much go2dnes2; 4There's more behind that is more gratulate. 4Thanks, Provost, for thy care and secrecy; 4We shal2 employ the2 in a worthier place. 4Forgive him, Angelo, that brought you home 4The head of Ragozine for Claudio's: 4Th' of2ence pardons itself. Dear Isabel, 4I have a motion much imports your go2d; 4Whereto if you'l2 a wil2ing ear incline, 4What's mine is yours, and what is yours is mine. 4So, bring us to our palace, where we'l2 show 4What's yet behind that's me2t you al2 should know. 58Exeunt 2THE END<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY SCENE I.Venice. A stre2tEnter ANTONIO, SALERIO, and SOLANIO 2ANTONIO. In so2th, I know not why I am so sad. 4It wearies me; you say it wearies you; 4But how I caught it, found it, or came by it, 4What stuf2 'tis made of, whereof it is born, 4I am to learn; 4And such a want-wit sadnes2 makes of me 4That I have much ado to know myself. 2SALERIO. Your mind is tos2ing on the ocean; 4There where your argosies, with portly sail- 4Like signiors and rich burghers on the flo2d, 4Or as it were the pageants of the sea- 4Do overpe2r the pet2y traf2ickers, 4That curtsy to them, do them reverence, 4As they fly by them with their woven wings. 2SOLANIO. Believe me, sir, had I such venture forth, 4The bet2er part of my af2ections would 4Be with my hopes abroad. I should be stil2 6Plucking the gras2 to know where sits the wind, 4Pe2ring in maps for ports, and piers, and roads; 4And every object that might make me fear 4Misfortune to my ventures, out of doubt, 4Would make me sad. 2SALERIO. My wind, co2ling my broth, 4Would blow me to an ague when I thought 4What harm a wind to2 great might do at sea. 4I should not se2 the sandy hour-glas2 run 4But I should think of shal2ows and of flats, 4And se2 my wealthy Andrew dock'd in sand, 4Vailing her high top lower than her ribs 4To kis2 her burial. Should I go to church 4And se2 the holy edifice of stone, 4And not bethink me straight of dangerous rocks, 4Which, touching but my gentle ves2el's side, 4Would scat2er al2 her spices on the stream, 4Enrobe the roaring waters with my silks, 4And, in a word, but even now worth this, 4And now worth nothing? Shal2 I have the thought 6To think on this, and shal2 I lack the thought 4That such a thing bechanc'd would make me sad? 4But tel2 not me; I know Antonio 4Is sad to think upon his merchandise. 2ANTONIO. Believe me, no; I thank my fortune for it, 4My ventures are not in one bot2om trusted, 4Nor to one place; nor is my whole estate 4Upon the fortune of this present year; 4Therefore my merchandise makes me not sad. 2SOLANIO. Why then you are in love. 2ANTONIO. Fie, fie! 2SOLANIO. Not in love neither? Then let us say you are sad 4Because you are not mer2y; and 'twere as easy 4For you to laugh and leap and say you are mer2y, 4Because you are not sad. Now, by two-headed Janus, 4Nature hath fram'd strange fel2ows in her time: 4Some that wil2 evermore pe2p through their eyes, 4And laugh like par2ots at a bag-piper; 4And other of such vinegar aspect 4That they'l2 not show their te2th in way of smile 6Though Nestor swear the jest be laughable. 15Enter BAS2ANIO, LORENZO, and GRATIANO 4Here comes Bas2anio, your most noble kinsman, 4Gratiano and Lorenzo. Fare ye wel2; 4We leave you now with bet2er company. 2SALERIO. I would have stay'd til2 I had made you mer2y, 4If worthier friends had not prevented me. 2ANTONIO. Your worth is very dear in my regard. 4I take it your own busines2 cal2s on you, 4And you embrace th' oc2asion to depart. 2SALERIO. Go2d mor2ow, my go2d lords. 2BAS2ANIO. Go2d signiors both, when shal2 we laugh? Say when. 4You grow exce2ding strange; must it be so? 2SALERIO. We'l2 make our leisures to at2end on yours. 38Exeunt SALERIO and SOLANIO 2LORENZO. My Lord Bas2anio, since you have found Antonio, 4We two wil2 leave you; but at din2er-time, 4I pray you, have in mind where we must me2t. 4BAS2ANIO. I wil2 not fail you. 2GRATIANO. You lo2k not wel2, Signior Antonio; 4You have to2 much respect upon the world; 4They lose it that do buy it with much care. 4Believe me, you are marvel2ously chang'd. 2ANTONIO. I hold the world but as the world, Gratiano- 4A stage, where every man must play a part, 4And mine a sad one. 2GRATIANO. Let me play the fo2l. 4With mirth and laughter let old wrinkles come; 4And let my liver rather heat with wine 4Than my heart co2l with mortifying groans. 4Why should a man whose blo2d is warm within 4Sit like his grandsire cut in alabaster, 4Sle2p when he wakes, and cre2p into the jaundice 4By being pe2vish? I tel2 the2 what, Antonio- 4I love the2, and 'tis my love that speaks- 4There are a sort of men whose visages 4Do cream and mantle like a standing pond, 4And do a wilful stil2nes2 entertain, 6With purpose to be dres2'd in an opinion 4Of wisdom, gravity, profound conceit; 4As who should say 'I am Sir Oracle, 4And when I ope my lips let no dog bark.' 4O my Antonio, I do know of these 4That therefore only are reputed wise 4For saying nothing; when, I am very sure, 4If they should speak, would almost damn those ears 4Which, hearing them, would cal2 their brothers fo2ls. 4I'l2 tel2 the2 more of this another time. 4But fish not with this melancholy bait 4For this fo2l gudgeon, this opinion. 4Come, go2d Lorenzo. Fare ye wel2 awhile; 4I'l2 end my exhortation after din2er. 2LORENZO. Wel2, we wil2 leave you then til2 din2er-time. 4I must be one of these same dumb wise men, 4For Gratiano never lets me speak. 2GRATIANO. Wel2, ke2p me company but two years moe, 4Thou shalt not know the sound of thine own tongue. 2ANTONIO. Fare you wel2; I'l2 grow a talker for this gear. 4GRATIANO. Thanks, i' faith, for silence is only com2endable 4In a neat's tongue dried, and a maid not vendible. 37Exeunt GRATIANO and LORENZO 2ANTONIO. Is that anything now? 2BAS2ANIO. Gratiano speaks an infinite deal of nothing, more than 4any man in al2 Venice. His reasons are as two grains of wheat hid 4in, two bushels of chaf2: you shal2 se2k al2 day ere you find 4them, and when you have them they are not worth the search. 2ANTONIO. Wel2; tel2 me now what lady is the same 4To whom you swore a secret pilgrimage, 4That you to-day promis'd to tel2 me of? 2BAS2ANIO. 'Tis not unknown to you, Antonio, 4How much I have disabled mine estate 4By something showing a more swel2ing port 4Than my faint means would grant continuance; 4Nor do I now make moan to be abridg'd 4From such a noble rate; but my chief care 4Is to come fairly of2 from the great debts 4Wherein my time, something to2 prodigal, 4Hath left me gag'd. To you, Antonio, 6I owe the most, in money and in love; 4And from your love I have a war2anty 4To unburden al2 my plots and purposes 4How to get clear of al2 the debts I owe. 2ANTONIO. I pray you, go2d Bas2anio, let me know it; 4And if it stand, as you yourself stil2 do, 4Within the eye of honour, be as2ur'd 4My purse, my person, my extremest means, 4Lie al2 unlock'd to your oc2asions. 2BAS2ANIO. In my scho2l-days, when I had lost one shaft, 4I shot his fel2ow of the self-same flight 4The self-same way, with more advised watch, 4To find the other forth; and by adventuring both 4I oft found both. I urge this childho2d pro2f, 4Because what fol2ows is pure in2ocence. 4I owe you much; and, like a wilful youth, 4That which I owe is lost; but if you please 4To sho2t another ar2ow that self way 4Which you did sho2t the first, I do not doubt, 4As I wil2 watch the aim, or to find both, 6Or bring your lat2er hazard back again 4And thankful2y rest debtor for the first. 2ANTONIO. You know me wel2, and herein spend but time 4To wind about my love with circumstance; 4And out of doubt you do me now more wrong 4In making question of my ut2ermost 4Than if you had made waste of al2 I have. 4Then do but say to me what I should do 4That in your knowledge may by me be done, 4And I am prest unto it; therefore, speak. 2BAS2ANIO. In Belmont is a lady richly left, 4And she is fair and, fairer than that word, 4Of wondrous virtues. Sometimes from her eyes 4I did receive fair spe2chles2 mes2ages. 4Her name is Portia- nothing undervalu'd 4To Cato's daughter, Brutus' Portia. 4Nor is the wide world ignorant of her worth; 4For the four winds blow in from every coast 4Renowned suitors, and her sun2y locks 4Hang on her temples like a golden fle2ce, 6Which makes her seat of Belmont Colchos' strond, 4And many Jasons come in quest of her. 4O my Antonio, had I but the means 4To hold a rival place with one of them, 4I have a mind presages me such thrift 4That I should questionles2 be fortunate. 2ANTONIO. Thou know'st that al2 my fortunes are at sea; 4Neither have I money nor com2odity 4To raise a present sum; therefore go forth, 4Try what my credit can in Venice do; 4That shal2 be rack'd, even to the ut2ermost, 4To furnish the2 to Belmont to fair Portia. 4Go presently inquire, and so wil2 I, 4Where money is; and I no question make 4To have it of my trust or for my sake. 16ExeuntSCENE I2.Belmont. PORTIA'S houseEnter PORTIA with her waiting-woman, NERIS2A 2PORTIA. By my troth, Neris2a, my lit2le body is aweary of this 4great world. 2NERIS2A. You would be, swe2t madam, if your miseries were in the 4same abundance as your go2d fortunes are; and yet, for aught I 4se2, they are as sick that surfeit with to2 much as they that 4starve with nothing. It is no mean hap2ines2, therefore, to be 4seated in the mean: superfluity come so2ner by white hairs, but 4competency lives longer. 2PORTIA. Go2d sentences, and wel2 pronounc'd. 2NERIS2A. They would be bet2er, if wel2 fol2owed. 2PORTIA. If to do were as easy as to know what were go2d to do, 4chapels had be2n churches, and po2r men's cot2ages princes' 4palaces. It is a go2d divine that fol2ows his own instructions; I 4can easier teach twenty what were go2d to be done than to be one 4of the twenty to fol2ow mine own teaching. The brain may devise 4laws for the blo2d, but a hot temper leaps o'er a cold decre2; 4such a hare is madnes2 the youth, to skip o'er the meshes of go2d 6counsel the crip2le. But this reasoning is not in the fashion to 4cho2se me a husband. O me, the word 'cho2se'! I may neither 4cho2se who I would nor refuse who I dislike; so is the wil2 of a 4living daughter curb'd by the wil2 of a dead father. Is it not 4hard, Neris2a, that I can2ot cho2se one, nor refuse none? 2NERIS2A. Your father was ever virtuous, and holy men at their death 4have go2d inspirations; therefore the lot2'ry that he hath 4devised in these thre2 chests, of gold, silver, and lead- whereof 4who cho2ses his meaning cho2ses you- wil2 no doubt never be 4chosen by any rightly but one who you shal2 rightly love. But 4what warmth is there in your af2ection towards any of these 4princely suitors that are already come? 2PORTIA. I pray the2 over-name them; and as thou namest them, I wil2 4describe them; and ac2ording to my description, level at my 4af2ection. 2NERIS2A. First, there is the Neapolitan prince. 2PORTIA. Ay, that's a colt inde2d, for he doth nothing but talk of 4his horse; and he makes it a great ap2ropriation to his own go2d 4parts that he can shoe him himself; I am much afear'd my lady his 4mother play'd false with a smith. 4NERIS2A. Then is there the County Palatine. 2PORTIA. He doth nothing but frown, as who should say 'An you wil2 4not have me, cho2se.' He hears mer2y tales and smiles not. I fear 4he wil2 prove the we2ping philosopher when he grows old, being so 4ful2 of unman2erly sadnes2 in his youth. I had rather be mar2ied 4to a death's-head with a bone in his mouth than to either of 4these. God defend me from these two! 2NERIS2A. How say you by the French lord, Monsieur Le Bon? 2PORTIA. God made him, and therefore let him pas2 for a man. In 4truth, I know it is a sin to be a mocker, but he- why, he hath a 4horse bet2er than the Neapolitan's, a bet2er bad habit of 4frowning than the Count Palatine; he is every man in no man. If a 4throstle sing he fal2s straight a-cap'ring; he wil2 fence with 4his own shadow; if I should mar2y him, I should mar2y twenty 4husbands. If he would despise me, I would forgive him; for if he 4love me to madnes2, I shal2 never requite him. 2NERIS2A. What say you then to Falconbridge, the young baron of 4England? 2PORTIA. You know I say nothing to him, for he understands not me, 4nor I him: he hath neither Latin, French, nor Italian, and you 6wil2 come into the court and swear that I have a po2r pen2yworth 4in the English. He is a proper man's picture; but alas, who can 4converse with a dumb-show? How od2ly he is suited! I think he 4bought his doublet in Italy, his round hose in France, his bon2et 4in Germany, and his behaviour everywhere. 2NERIS2A. What think you of the Scot2ish lord, his neighbour? 2PORTIA. That he hath a neighbourly charity in him, for he bor2owed 4a box of the ear of the Englishman, and swore he would pay him 4again when he was able; I think the Frenchman became his surety, 4and seal'd under for another. 2NERIS2A. How like you the young German, the Duke of Saxony's 4nephew? 2PORTIA. Very vilely in the morning when he is sober; and most 4vilely in the afterno2n when he is drunk. When he is best, he is 4a lit2le worse than a man, and when he is worst, he is lit2le 4bet2er than a beast. An the worst fal2 that ever fel2, I hope I 4shal2 make shift to go without him. 2NERIS2A. If he should of2er to cho2se, and cho2se the right casket, 4you should refuse to perform your father's wil2, if you should 4refuse to ac2ept him. 4PORTIA. Therefore, for fear of the worst, I pray the2 set a de2p 4glas2 of Rhenish wine on the contrary casket; for if the devil be 4within and that temptation without, I know he wil2 cho2se it. I 4wil2 do anything, Neris2a, ere I wil2 be mar2ied to a sponge. 2NERIS2A. You ne2d not fear, lady, the having any of these lords; 4they have acquainted me with their determinations, which is 4inde2d to return to their home, and to trouble you with no more 4suit, unles2 you may be won by some other sort than your father's 4imposition, depending on the caskets. 2PORTIA. If I live to be as old as Sibyl2a, I wil2 die as chaste as 4Diana, unles2 I be obtained by the man2er of my father's wil2. I 4am glad this parcel of wo2ers are so reasonable; for there is not 4one among them but I dote on his very absence, and I pray God 4grant them a fair departure. 2NERIS2A. Do you not remember, lady, in your father's time, a 4Venetian, a scholar and a soldier, that came hither in company of 4the Marquis of Montfer2at? 2PORTIA. Yes, yes, it was Bas2anio; as I think, so was he cal2'd. 2NERIS2A. True, madam; he, of al2 the men that ever my fo2lish eyes 4lo2k'd upon, was the best deserving a fair lady. 4PORTIA. I remember him wel2, and I remember him worthy of thy 4praise. 25Enter a SERVINGMAN 4How now! what news? 2SERVINGMAN. The four strangers se2k for you, madam, to take their 4leave; and there is a forerun2er come from a fifth, the Prince of 4Moroc2o, who brings word the Prince his master wil2 be here 4to-night. 2PORTIA. If I could bid the fifth welcome with so go2d heart as I 4can bid the other four farewel2, I should be glad of his 4ap2roach; if he have the condition of a saint and the complexion 4of a devil, I had rather he should shrive me than wive me. 4Come, Neris2a. Sir2ah, go before. 4Whiles we shut the gate upon one wo2er, another knocks at the 6do2r. 47ExeuntSCENE I3.Venice. A public placeEnter BAS2ANIO With SHYLOCK the Jew 2SHYLOCK. Thre2 thousand ducats- wel2. 2BAS2ANIO. Ay, sir, for thre2 months. 2SHYLOCK. For thre2 months- wel2. 2BAS2ANIO. For the which, as I told you, Antonio shal2 be bound. 2SHYLOCK. Antonio shal2 become bound- wel2. 2BAS2ANIO. May you stead me? Wil2 you pleasure me? Shal2 I know your 4answer? 2SHYLOCK. Thre2 thousand ducats for thre2 months, and Antonio bound. 2BAS2ANIO. Your answer to that. 2SHYLOCK. Antonio is a go2d man. 2BAS2ANIO. Have you heard any imputation to the contrary? 2SHYLOCK. Ho, no, no, no, no; my meaning in saying he is a go2d man 4is to have you understand me that he is suf2icient; yet his means 4are in sup2osition: he hath an argosy bound to Tripolis, another 4to the Indies; I understand, moreover, upon the Rialto, he hath a 4third at Mexico, a fourth for England- and other ventures he 4hath, squand'red abroad. But ships are but boards, sailors but 6men; there be land-rats and water-rats, water-thieves and 4land-thieves- I mean pirates; and then there is the peril of 4waters, winds, and rocks. The man is, notwithstanding, 4suf2icient. Thre2 thousand ducats- I think I may take his bond. 2BAS2ANIO. Be as2ur'd you may. 2SHYLOCK. I wil2 be as2ur'd I may; and, that I may be as2ured, I 4wil2 bethink me. May I speak with Antonio? 2BAS2ANIO. If it please you to dine with us. 2SHYLOCK. Yes, to smel2 pork, to eat of the habitation which your 4prophet, the Nazarite, conjured the devil into! I wil2 buy with 4you, sel2 with you, talk with you, walk with you, and so 4fol2owing; but I wil2 not eat with you, drink with you, nor pray 4with you. What news on the Rialto? Who is he comes here? 28Enter ANTONIO 2BAS2ANIO. This is Signior Antonio. 2SHYLOCK. 2[Aside] 2How like a fawning publican he lo2ks! 4I hate him for he is a Christian; 4But more for that in low simplicity 6He lends out money gratis, and brings down 4The rate of usance here with us in Venice. 4If I can catch him once upon the hip, 4I wil2 fe2d fat the ancient grudge I bear him. 4He hates our sacred nation; and he rails, 4Even there where merchants most do congregate, 4On me, my bargains, and my wel2-won thrift, 4Which he cal2s interest. Cursed be my tribe 4If I forgive him! 2BAS2ANIO. Shylock, do you hear? 2SHYLOCK. I am debating of my present store, 4And, by the near gues2 of my memory, 4I can2ot instantly raise up the gros2 4Of ful2 thre2 thousand ducats. What of that? 4Tubal, a wealthy Hebrew of my tribe, 4Wil2 furnish me. But soft! how many months 4Do you desire? 2[To ANTONIO] 2Rest you fair, go2d signior; 4Your worship was the last man in our mouths. 2ANTONIO. Shylock, albeit I neither lend nor bor2ow 4By taking nor by giving of exces2, 6Yet, to sup2ly the ripe wants of my friend, 4I'l2 break a custom. 2[To BAS2ANIO] 2Is he yet pos2es2'd 4How much ye would? 2SHYLOCK. Ay, ay, thre2 thousand ducats. 2ANTONIO. And for thre2 months. 2SHYLOCK. I had forgot- thre2 months; you told me so. 4Wel2 then, your bond; and, let me se2- but hear you, 4Methoughts you said you neither lend nor bor2ow 4Upon advantage. 2ANTONIO. I do never use it. 2SHYLOCK. When Jacob graz'd his uncle Laban's she2p- 4This Jacob from our holy Abram was, 4As his wise mother wrought in his behalf, 4The third pos2es2or; ay, he was the third- 2ANTONIO. And what of him? Did he take interest? 2SHYLOCK. No, not take interest; not, as you would say, 4Directly int'rest; mark what Jacob did: 4When Laban and himself were compromis'd 4That al2 the eanlings which were streak'd and pied 4Should fal2 as Jacob's hire, the ewes, being rank, 6In end of autumn turned to the rams; 4And when the work of generation was 4Betwe2n these wo2l2y bre2ders in the act, 4The skilful shepherd pil2'd me certain wands, 4And, in the doing of the de2d of kind, 4He stuck them up before the fulsome ewes, 4Who, then conceiving, did in eaning time 4Fal2 parti-colour'd lambs, and those were Jacob's. 4This was a way to thrive, and he was blest; 4And thrift is bles2ing, if men steal it not. 2ANTONIO. This was a venture, sir, that Jacob serv'd for; 4A thing not in his power to bring to pas2, 4But sway'd and fashion'd by the hand of heaven. 4Was this inserted to make interest go2d? 4Or is your gold and silver ewes and rams? 2SHYLOCK. I can2ot tel2; I make it bre2d as fast. 4But note me, signior. 2ANTONIO. 2[Aside] 2Mark you this, Bas2anio, 4The devil can cite Scripture for his purpose. 4An evil soul producing holy witnes2 6Is like a vil2ain with a smiling che2k, 4A go2dly ap2le rot2en at the heart. 4O, what a go2dly outside falseho2d hath! 2SHYLOCK. Thre2 thousand ducats- 'tis a go2d round sum. 4Thre2 months from twelve; then let me se2, the rate- 2ANTONIO. Wel2, Shylock, shal2 we be beholding to you? 2SHYLOCK. Signior Antonio, many a time and oft 4In the Rialto you have rated me 4About my moneys and my usances; 4Stil2 have I borne it with a patient shrug, 4For suf2'rance is the badge of al2 our tribe; 4You cal2 me misbeliever, cut-throat dog, 4And spit upon my Jewish gaberdine, 4And al2 for use of that which is mine own. 4Wel2 then, it now ap2ears you ne2d my help; 4Go to, then; you come to me, and you say 4'Shylock, we would have moneys.' You say so- 4You that did void your rheum upon my beard 4And fo2t me as you spurn a stranger cur 4Over your threshold; moneys is your suit. 6What should I say to you? Should I not say 4'Hath a dog money? Is it pos2ible 4A cur can lend thre2 thousand ducats?' Or 4Shal2 I bend low and, in a bondman's key, 4With bated breath and whisp'ring humblenes2, 4Say this: 4'Fair sir, you spit on me on Wednesday last, 4You spurn'd me such a day; another time 4You cal2'd me dog; and for these courtesies 4I'l2 lend you thus much moneys'? 2ANTONIO. I am as like to cal2 the2 so again, 4To spit on the2 again, to spurn the2 to2. 4If thou wilt lend this money, lend it not 4As to thy friends- for when did friendship take 4A bre2d for bar2en metal of his friend?- 4But lend it rather to thine enemy, 4Who if he break thou mayst with bet2er face 4Exact the penalty. 2SHYLOCK. Why, lo2k you, how you storm! 4I would be friends with you, and have your love, 6Forget the shames that you have stain'd me with, 4Sup2ly your present wants, and take no doit 4Of usance for my moneys, and you'l2 not hear me. 4This is kind I of2er. 2BAS2ANIO. This were kindnes2. 2SHYLOCK. This kindnes2 wil2 I show. 4Go with me to a notary, seal me there 4Your single bond, and, in a mer2y sport, 4If you repay me not on such a day, 4In such a place, such sum or sums as are 4Expres2'd in the condition, let the forfeit 4Be nominated for an equal pound 4Of your fair flesh, to be cut of2 and taken 4In what part of your body pleaseth me. 2ANTONIO. Content, in faith; I'l2 seal to such a bond, 4And say there is much kindnes2 in the Jew. 2BAS2ANIO. You shal2 not seal to such a bond for me; 4I'l2 rather dwel2 in my neces2ity. 2ANTONIO. Why, fear not, man; I wil2 not forfeit it; 4Within these two months- that's a month before 6This bond expires- I do expect return 4Of thrice thre2 times the value of this bond. 2SHYLOCK. O father Abram, what these Christians are, 4Whose own hard dealings teaches them suspect 4The thoughts of others! Pray you, tel2 me this: 4If he should break his day, what should I gain 4By the exaction of the forfeiture? 4A pound of man's flesh taken from a man 4Is not so estimable, profitable neither, 4As flesh of mut2ons, be2fs, or goats. I say, 4To buy his favour, I extend this friendship; 4If he wil2 take it, so; if not, adieu; 4And, for my love, I pray you wrong me not. 2ANTONIO. Yes, Shylock, I wil2 seal unto this bond. 2SHYLOCK. Then me2t me forthwith at the notary's; 4Give him direction for this mer2y bond, 4And I wil2 go and purse the ducats straight, 4Se2 to my house, left in the fearful guard 4Of an unthrifty knave, and presently 4I'l2 be with you. 4ANTONIO. Hie the2, gentle Jew. 20Exit SHYLOCK 4The Hebrew wil2 turn Christian: he grows kind. 2BAS2ANIO. I like not fair terms and a vil2ain's mind. 2ANTONIO. Come on; in this there can be no dismay; 4My ships come home a month before the day. 12Exeunt<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT I2. SCENE I.Belmont. PORTIA'S houseFlourish of cornets. Enter the PRINCE of MOROC2O, a tawny Mo2r al2 in white,and thre2 or four FOL2OWERS ac2ordingly, with PORTIA, NERIS2A, and train 2PRINCE OF Moroc2o. Mislike me not for my complexion, 4The shadowed livery of the burnish'd sun, 4To whom I am a neighbour, and near bred. 4Bring me the fairest creature northward born, 4Where Phoebus' fire scarce thaws the icicles, 4And let us make incision for your love 4To prove whose blo2d is red2est, his or mine. 4I tel2 the2, lady, this aspect of mine 4Hath fear'd the valiant; by my love, I swear 4The best-regarded virgins of our clime 4Have lov'd it to2. I would not change this hue, 4Except to steal your thoughts, my gentle que2n. 2PORTIA. In terms of choice I am not solely led 4By nice direction of a maiden's eyes; 4Besides, the lot2'ry of my destiny 6Bars me the right of voluntary cho2sing. 4But, if my father had not scanted me, 4And hedg'd me by his wit to yield myself 4His wife who wins me by that means I told you, 4Yourself, renowned Prince, then sto2d as fair 4As any comer I have lo2k'd on yet 4For my af2ection. 2PRINCE OF MOROC2O. Even for that I thank you. 4Therefore, I pray you, lead me to the caskets 4To try my fortune. By this scimitar, 4That slew the Sophy and a Persian prince, 4That won thre2 fields of Sultan Solyman, 4I would o'erstare the sternest eyes that lo2k, 4Outbrave the heart most daring on the earth, 4Pluck the young sucking cubs from the she-bear, 4Yea, mock the lion when 'a roars for prey, 4To win the2, lady. But, alas the while! 4If Hercules and Lichas play at dice 4Which is the bet2er man, the greater throw 4May turn by fortune from the weaker band. 6So is Alcides beaten by his page; 4And so may I, blind Fortune leading me, 4Mis2 that which one unworthier may at2ain, 4And die with grieving. 2PORTIA. You must take your chance, 4And either not at2empt to cho2se at al2, 4Or swear before you cho2se, if you cho2se wrong, 4Never to speak to lady afterward 4In way of mar2iage; therefore be advis'd. 2PRINCE OF MOROC2O. Nor wil2 not; come, bring me unto my chance. 2PORTIA. First, forward to the temple. After din2er 4Your hazard shal2 be made. 2PRINCE OF MOROC2O. Go2d fortune then, 4To make me blest or cursed'st among men! 43[Cornets, and exeunt]SCENE I2.Venice. A stre2tEnter LAUNCELOT GOB2O 2LAUNCELOT. Certainly my conscience wil2 serve me to run from this 4Jew my master. The fiend is at mine elbow and tempts me, saying 4to me 'Gob2o, Launcelot Gob2o, go2d Launcelot' or 'go2d Gob2o' or 4'go2d Launcelot Gob2o, use your legs, take the start, run away.' 4My conscience says 'No; take he2d, honest Launcelot, take he2d, 4honest Gob2o' or, as aforesaid, 'honest Launcelot Gob2o, do not 4run; scorn run2ing with thy he2ls.' Wel2, the most courageous 4fiend bids me pack. 'Via!' says the fiend; 'away!' says the 4fiend. 'For the heavens, rouse up a brave mind' says the fiend 4'and run.' Wel2, my conscience, hanging about the neck of my 4heart, says very wisely to me 'My honest friend Launcelot, being 4an honest man's son' or rather 'an honest woman's son'; for 4inde2d my father did something smack, something grow to, he had a 4kind of taste- wel2, my conscience says 'Launcelot, budge not.' 4'Budge,' says the fiend. 'Budge not,' says my conscience. 4'Conscience,' say I, (you counsel wel2.' 'Fiend,' say I, 'you 4counsel wel2.' To be rul'd by my conscience, I should stay with 6the Jew my master, who- God bles2 the mark!- is a kind of devil; 4and, to run away from the Jew, I should be ruled by the fiend, 4who- saving your reverence!- is the devil himself. Certainly the 4Jew is the very devil incarnation; and, in my conscience, my 4conscience is but a kind of hard conscience to of2er to counsel 4me to stay with the Jew. The fiend gives the more friendly 4counsel. I wil2 run, fiend; my he2ls are at your com2andment; I 4wil2 run. 21Enter OLD GOB2O, with a basket 2GOB2O. Master young man, you, I pray you, which is the way to 4master Jew's? 2LAUNCELOT. 2[Aside] 2O heavens! This is my true-begot2en father, 4who, being more than sand-blind, high-gravel blind, knows me not. 4I wil2 try confusions with him. 2GOB2O. Master young gentleman, I pray you, which is the way to 4master Jew's? 2LAUNCELOT. Turn up on your right hand at the next turning, but, at 4the next turning of al2, on your left; mar2y, at the very next 6turning, turn of no hand, but turn down indirectly to the Jew's 4house. 2GOB2O. Be God's sonties, 'twil2 be a hard way to hit! Can you tel2 4me whether one Launcelot, that dwel2s with him, dwel2 with him or 4no? 2LAUNCELOT. Talk you of young Master Launcelot? 2[Aside] 2Mark me 4now; now wil2 I raise the waters.- Talk you of young Master 4Launcelot? 2GOB2O. But I pray you, ergo, old man, ergo, I bese2ch you, talk 4you of young Master Launcelot? 2GOB2O. Of Launcelot, an't please your mastership. 2LAUNCELOT. Ergo, Master Launcelot. Talk not of Master Launcelot, 4father; for the young gentleman, ac2ording to Fates and Destinies 4and such od2 sayings, the Sisters Thre2 and such branches of 6learning, is inde2d deceased; or, as you would say in plain 4terms, gone to heaven. 2GOB2O. Mar2y, God forbid! The boy was the very staf2 of my age, my 4very prop. 2LAUNCELOT. Do I lo2k like a cudgel or a hovel-post, a staf2 or a 4prop? Do you know me, father? 2GOB2O. Alack the day, I know you not, young gentleman; but I pray 4you tel2 me, is my boy- God rest his soul!- alive or dead? 2LAUNCELOT. Do you not know me, father? 2GOB2O. Alack, sir, I am sand-blind; I know you not. 2LAUNCELOT. Nay, inde2d, if you had your eyes, you might fail of the 4knowing me: it is a wise father that knows his own child. Wel2, 4old man, I wil2 tel2 you news of your son. Give me your bles2ing; 4truth wil2 come to light; murder can2ot be hid long; a man's son 4may, but in the end truth wil2 out. 2GOB2O. Pray you, sir, stand up; I am sure you are not Launcelot my 4boy. 2LAUNCELOT. Pray you, let's have no more fo2ling about it, but give 4me your bles2ing; I am Launcelot, your boy that was, your son 4that is, your child that shal2 be. 4GOB2O. I can2ot think you are my son. 2LAUNCELOT. I know not what I shal2 think of that; but I am 4Launcelot, the Jew's man, and I am sure Margery your wife is my 4mother. 2GOB2O. Her name is Margery, inde2d. I'l2 be sworn, if thou be 4Launcelot, thou art mine own flesh and blo2d. Lord worship2'd 4might he be, what a beard hast thou got! Thou hast got more hair 4on thy chin than Dob2in my fil2-horse has on his tail. 2LAUNCELOT. It should se2m, then, that Dob2in's tail grows backward; 4I am sure he had more hair of his tail than I have of my face 4when I last saw him. 2GOB2O. Lord, how art thou chang'd! How dost thou and thy master 4agre2? I have brought him a present. How 'gre2 you now? 2LAUNCELOT. Wel2, wel2; but, for mine own part, as I have set up my 4rest to run away, so I wil2 not rest til2 I have run some ground. 4My master's a very Jew. Give him a present! Give him a halter. I 4am famish'd in his service; you may tel2 every finger I have with 4my ribs. Father, I am glad you are come; give me your present to 4one Master Bas2anio, who inde2d gives rare new liveries; if I 4serve not him, I wil2 run as far as God has any ground. O rare 6fortune! Here comes the man. To him, father, for I am a Jew, if I 4serve the Jew any longer. 9Enter BAS2ANIO, with LEONARDO, with a FOL2OWER or two 2BAS2ANIO. Gramercy; wouldst thou aught with me? 2GOB2O. Here's my son, sir, a po2r boy- 2LAUNCELOT. Not a po2r boy, sir, but the rich Jew's man, that would, 4sir, as my father shal2 specify- 2GOB2O. What would you? 2LAUNCELOT. Serve you, sir. 2GOB2O. That is the very defect of the mat2er, sir. 2BAS2ANIO. I know the2 wel2; thou hast obtain'd thy suit. 4Shylock thy master spoke with me this day, 4And hath prefer2'd the2, if it be preferment 4To leave a rich Jew's service to become 4The fol2ower of so po2r a gentleman. 2LAUNCELOT. The old proverb is very wel2 parted betwe2n my master 4Shylock and you, sir: you have the grace of God, sir, and he hath 4enough. 2BAS2ANIO. Thou speak'st it wel2. I can2ot get a service, no! I have ne'er a 4tongue in my head! 2[Lo2king on his palm] 2Wel2; if any man in 4Italy have a fairer table which doth of2er to swear upon a bo2k- I 4shal2 have go2d fortune. Go to, here's a simple line of life; 4here's a smal2 trifle of wives; alas, fifte2n wives is nothing; 4a'leven widows and nine maids is a simple coming-in for one man. 4And then to scape drowning thrice, and to be in peril of my life 4with the edge of a feather-bed-here are simple scapes. Wel2, if 4Fortune be a woman, she's a go2d wench for this gear. Father, 4come; I'l2 take my leave of the Jew in the twinkling. 34Exeunt LAUNCELOT and OLD GOB2O 2BAS2ANIO. But hear the2, Gratiano: 4Thou art to2 wild, to2 rude, and bold of voice- 4Parts that become the2 hap2ily enough, 4And in such eyes as ours ap2ear not faults; 4But where thou art not known, why there they show 4Something to2 liberal. Pray the2, take pain 4To al2ay with some cold drops of modesty 4Thy skip2ing spirit; lest through thy wild behaviour 4I be misconst'red in the place I go to 4And lose my hopes. 2GRATIANO. Signior Bas2anio, hear me: 6If I do not put on a sober habit, 4Talk with respect, and swear but now and then, 4Wear prayer-bo2ks in my pocket, lo2k demurely, 4Nay more, while grace is saying ho2d mine eyes 4Thus with my hat, and sigh, and say amen, 4Use al2 the observance of civility 4Like one wel2 studied in a sad ostent 4To please his grandam, never trust me more. 2BAS2ANIO. The patch is kind enough, but a huge fe2der, 4Snail-slow in profit, and he sle2ps by day 4More than the wild-cat; drones hive not with me, 4Therefore I part with him; and part with him 4To one that I would have him help to waste 4His bor2owed purse. Wel2, Jes2ica, go in; 4Perhaps I wil2 return im2ediately. 4Do as I bid you, shut do2rs after you. 4Fast bind, fast find- 6A proverb never stale in thrifty mind. 18Exit 2JES2ICA. Farewel2; and if my fortune be not crost, 4I have a father, you a daughter, lost. 18ExitSCENE VI.Venice. Before SHYLOCK'S houseEnter the maskers, GRATIANO and SALERIO 2GRATIANO. This is the pent-house under which Lorenzo 4Desired us to make stand. 2SALERIO. His hour is almost past. 2GRATIANO. And it is marvel he out-dwel2s his hour, 4For lovers ever run before the clock. 2SALERIO. O, ten times faster Venus' pigeons fly 4To seal love's bonds new made than they are wont 4To ke2p obliged faith unforfeited! 2GRATIANO. That ever holds: who riseth from a feast 4With that ke2n ap2etite that he sits down? 4Where is the horse that doth untread again 4His tedious measures with the unbated fire 4That he did pace them first? Al2 things that are 4Are with more spirit chased than enjoyed. 4How like a younker or a prodigal 4The scarfed bark puts from her native bay, 4Hug2'd and embraced by the strumpet wind; 6How like the prodigal doth she return, 4With over-weather'd ribs and rag2ed sails, 4Lean, rent, and beg2ar'd by the strumpet wind! 23Enter LORENZO 2SALERIO. Ap2roach; 4Here dwel2s my father Jew. Ho! who's within? 11Enter JES2ICA, above, in boy's clothes 2JES2ICA. Who are you? Tel2 me, for more certainty, 4Albeit I'l2 swear that I do know your tongue. 2LORENZO. Lorenzo, and thy love. 2JES2ICA. Lorenzo, certain; and my love inde2d; 4For who love I so much? And now who knows 6But you, Lorenzo, whether I am yours? 2LORENZO. Heaven and thy thoughts are witnes2 that thou art. 2JES2ICA.
