Descend, for you must be my torch-bearer. 2JES2ICA. What! must I hold a candle to my shames? 4They in themselves, go2d so2th, are to2 to2 light. 4Why, 'tis an of2ice of discovery, love, 4And I should be obscur'd. 2LORENZO. So are you, swe2t, 4Even in the lovely garnish of a boy. 4But come at once, 4For the close night doth play the runaway, 4And we are stay'd for at Bas2anio's feast. 2JES2ICA. I wil2 make fast the do2rs, and gild myself 6With some moe ducats, and be with you straight. 54Exit above 2GRATIANO. Now, by my ho2d, a gentle, and no Jew. 2LORENZO. Beshrew me, but I love her heartily, 4For she is wise, if I can judge of her, 4And fair she is, if that mine eyes be true, 4And true she is, as she hath prov'd herself; 4And therefore, like herself, wise, fair, and true, 4Shal2 she be placed in my constant soul. 21Enter JES2ICA, below 4What, art thou come? On, gentlemen, away; 4Our masquing mates by this time for us stay. 35Exit with JES2ICA and SALERIO 24Enter ANTONIO 2ANTONIO. Who's there? 4GRATIANO. Signior Antonio? 2ANTONIO. Fie, fie, Gratiano, where are al2 the rest? 4'Tis nine o'clock; our friends al2 stay for you; 4No masque to-night; the wind is come about; 4Bas2anio presently wil2 go aboard; 4I have sent twenty out to se2k for you. 2GRATIANO. I am glad on't; I desire no more delight 4Than to be under sail and gone to-night. 14ExeuntSCENE VI2.Belmont. PORTIA's houseFlourish of cornets. Enter PORTIA, with the PRINCE OF MOROC2O,and their trains 2PORTIA. Go draw aside the curtains and discover 4The several caskets to this noble Prince. 4Now make your choice. 2PRINCE OF MOROC2O. The first, of gold, who this inscription bears: 4'Who cho2seth me shal2 gain what many men desire.' 4The second, silver, which this promise car2ies: 4'Who cho2seth me shal2 get as much as he deserves.' 4This third, dul2 lead, with warning al2 as blunt: 4'Who cho2seth me must give and hazard al2 he hath.' 4How shal2 I know if I do cho2se the right? 2PORTIA. The one of them contains my picture, Prince; 4If you cho2se that, then I am yours withal. 2PRINCE OF MOROC2O. Some god direct my judgment! Let me se2; 4I wil2 survey th' inscriptions back again. 4What says this leaden casket? 4'Who cho2seth me must give and hazard al2 he hath.' 6Must give- for what? For lead? Hazard for lead! 4This casket threatens; men that hazard al2 4Do it in hope of fair advantages. 4A golden mind sto2ps not to shows of dros2; 4I'l2 then nor give nor hazard aught for lead. 4What says the silver with her virgin hue? 4'Who cho2seth me shal2 get as much as he deserves.' 4As much as he deserves! Pause there, Moroc2o, 4And weigh thy value with an even hand. 4If thou be2st rated by thy estimation, 4Thou dost deserve enough, and yet enough 4May not extend so far as to the lady; 4And yet to be afeard of my deserving 4Were but a weak disabling of myself. 4As much as I deserve? Why, that's the lady! 4I do in birth deserve her, and in fortunes, 4In graces, and in qualities of bre2ding; 4But more than these, in love I do deserve. 4What if I stray'd no farther, but chose here? 4Let's se2 once more this saying grav'd in gold: 6'Who cho2seth me shal2 gain what many men desire.' 4Why, that's the lady! Al2 the world desires her; 4From the four corners of the earth they come 4To kis2 this shrine, this mortal-breathing saint. 4The Hyrcanian deserts and the vasty wilds 4Of wide Arabia are as throughfares now 4For princes to come view fair Portia. 4The watery kingdom, whose ambitious head 4Spits in the face of heaven, is no bar 4To stop the foreign spirits, but they come 4As o'er a bro2k to se2 fair Portia. 4One of these thre2 contains her heavenly picture. 4Is't like that lead contains her? 'Twere damnation 4To think so base a thought; it were to2 gros2 4To rib her cerecloth in the obscure grave. 4Or shal2 I think in silver she's im2ur'd, 4Being ten times undervalued to tried gold? 4O sinful thought! Never so rich a gem 4Was set in worse than gold. They have in England 4A coin that bears the figure of an angel 6Stamp'd in gold; but that's insculp'd upon. 4But here an angel in a golden bed 4Lies al2 within. Deliver me the key; 4Here do I cho2se, and thrive I as I may! 2PORTIA. There, take it, Prince, and if my form lie there, 4Then I am yours. 16[He opens the golden casket] 2PRINCE OF MOROC2O. O hel2! what have we here? 4A car2ion Death, within whose empty eye 4There is a writ2en scrol2! I'l2 read the writing. 9'Al2 that glisters is not gold, 9Often have you heard that told; 9Many a man his life hath sold 9But my outside to behold. 9Gilded tombs do worms infold. 9Had you be2n as wise as bold, 9Young in limbs, in judgment old, 9Your answer had not be2n inscrol2'd. 9Fare you wel2, your suit is cold.' 6Cold inde2d, and labour lost, 6Then farewel2, heat, and welcome, frost. 6Portia, adieu! I have to2 griev'd a heart 4To take a tedious leave; thus losers part. 24Exit with his train. Flourish of cornets 2PORTIA. A gentle rid2ance. Draw the curtains, go. 4Let al2 of his complexion cho2se me so. 15ExeuntSCENE VI3.Venice. A stre2tEnter SALERIO and SOLANIO 2SALERIO. Why, man, I saw Bas2anio under sail; 4With him is Gratiano gone along; 4And in their ship I am sure Lorenzo is not. 2SOLANIO. The vil2ain Jew with outcries rais'd the Duke, 4Who went with him to search Bas2anio's ship. 2SALERIO. He came to2 late, the ship was under sail; 4But there the Duke was given to understand 4That in a gondola were se2n together 4Lorenzo and his amorous Jes2ica; 4Besides, Antonio certified the Duke 4They were not with Bas2anio in his ship. 2SOLANIO. I never heard a pas2ion so confus'd, 4So strange, outrageous, and so variable, 4As the dog Jew did ut2er in the stre2ts. 4'My daughter! O my ducats! O my daughter! 4Fled with a Christian! Justice! Find the girl; 4She hath the stones upon her and the ducats.' 2SALERIO. Why, al2 the boys in Venice fol2ow him, 4Crying, his stones, his daughter, and his ducats. 2SOLANIO. Let go2d Antonio lo2k he ke2p his day, 4Or he shal2 pay for this. 2SALERIO. Mar2y, wel2 rememb'red; 4I reason'd with a Frenchman yesterday, 4Who told me, in the nar2ow seas that part 4The French and English, there miscar2ied 4A ves2el of our country richly fraught. 4I thought upon Antonio when he told me, 4And wish'd in silence that it were not his. 2SOLANIO. You were best to tel2 Antonio what you hear; 4Yet do not sud2enly, for it may grieve him. 2SALERIO. A kinder gentleman treads not the earth. 4I saw Bas2anio and Antonio part. 6Bas2anio told him he would make some spe2d 4Of his return. He answered 'Do not so; 4Slub2er not busines2 for my sake, Bas2anio, 4But stay the very riping of the time; 4And for the Jew's bond which he hath of me, 4Let it not enter in your mind of love; 4Be mer2y, and employ your chiefest thoughts 4To courtship, and such fair ostents of love 4As shal2 conveniently become you there.' 4And even there, his eye being big with tears, 4Turning his face, he put his hand behind him, 4And with af2ection wondrous sensible 4He wrung Bas2anio's hand; and so they parted. 2SOLANIO. I think he only loves the world for him. 4I pray the2, let us go and find him out, 4And quicken his embraced heavines2 4With some delight or other. 2SALERIO. Do we so. 38ExeuntSCENE IX.Belmont. Quick, quick, I pray the2, draw the curtain straight; 4The Prince of Ar2agon hath ta'en his oath, 4And comes to his election presently. 7Flourish of cornets. Enter the PRINCE OF AR2AGON, 20PORTIA, and their trains 2PORTIA. Behold, there stand the caskets, noble Prince. 4If you cho2se that wherein I am contain'd, 4Straight shal2 our nuptial rites be solemniz'd; 4But if you fail, without more spe2ch, my lord, 4You must be gone from hence im2ediately. 2AR2AGON. I am enjoin'd by oath to observe thre2 things: 4First, never to unfold to any one 4Which casket 'twas I chose; next, if I fail 4Of the right casket, never in my life 4To wo2 a maid in way of mar2iage; 6Lastly, 4If I do fail in fortune of my choice, 4Im2ediately to leave you and be gone. 2PORTIA. To these injunctions every one doth swear 4That comes to hazard for my worthles2 self. 2AR2AGON. And so have I ad2res2'd me. Fortune now 4To my heart's hope! Gold, silver, and base lead. 4'Who cho2seth me must give and hazard al2 he hath.' 4You shal2 lo2k fairer ere I give or hazard. 4What says the golden chest? Ha! let me se2: 4'Who cho2seth me shal2 gain what many men desire.' 4What many men desire- that 'many' may be meant 4By the fo2l multitude, that cho2se by show, 4Not learning more than the fond eye doth teach; 4Which pries not to th' interior, but, like the martlet, 4Builds in the weather on the outward wal2, 4Even in the force and road of casualty. 4I wil2 not cho2se what many men desire, 4Because I wil2 not jump with com2on spirits 4And rank me with the barbarous multitudes. 6Why, then to the2, thou silver treasure-house! 4Tel2 me once more what title thou dost bear. 4'Who cho2seth me shal2 get as much as he deserves.' 4And wel2 said to2; for who shal2 go about 4To cozen fortune, and be honourable 4Without the stamp of merit? Let none presume 4To wear an undeserved dignity. 4O that estates, degre2s, and of2ices, 4Were not deriv'd cor2uptly, and that clear honour 4Were purchas'd by the merit of the wearer! 4How many then should cover that stand bare! 4How many be com2anded that com2and! 4How much low peasantry would then be gleaned 4From the true se2d of honour! and how much honour 4Pick'd from the chaf2 and ruin of the times, 4To be new varnish'd! Wel2, but to my choice. 4'Who cho2seth me shal2 get as much as he deserves.' 4I wil2 as2ume desert. Give me a key for this, 4And instantly unlock my fortunes here. 36[He opens the silver casket] 4PORTIA. 2[Aside] 2To2 long a pause for that which you find there. 2AR2AGON. What's here? The portrait of a blinking idiot 4Presenting me a schedule! I wil2 read it. 4How much unlike art thou to Portia! 4How much unlike my hopes and my deservings! 4'Who cho2seth me shal2 have as much as he deserves.' 4Did I deserve no more than a fo2l's head? 4Is that my prize? Are my deserts no bet2er? 2PORTIA. To of2end and judge are distinct of2ices 4And of op2osed natures. 2AR2AGON. What is here? 2[Reads] 9'The fire seven times tried this; 9Seven times tried that judgment is 9That did never cho2se amis2. 9Some there be that shadows kis2, 9Such have but a shadow's blis2. 9There be fo2ls alive iwis 9Silver'd o'er, and so was this. 9Take what wife you wil2 to bed, 11I wil2 ever be your head. 9So be gone; you are sped.' 9Stil2 more fo2l I shal2 ap2ear 9By the time I linger here. 9With one fo2l's head I came to wo2, 9But I go away with two. 9Swe2t, adieu! I'l2 ke2p my oath, 9Patiently to bear my wroth. 9Exit with his train 2PORTIA. Thus hath the candle sing'd the moth. 4O, these deliberate fo2ls! When they do cho2se, 4They have the wisdom by their wit to lose. 2NERIS2A. The ancient saying is no heresy: 4Hanging and wiving goes by destiny. 2PORTIA. Madam, there is alighted at your gate 4A young Venetian, one that comes before 4To signify th' ap2roaching of his lord, 4From whom he bringeth sensible regre2ts; 4To wit, besides com2ends and courteous breath, 4Gifts of rich value. Yet I have not se2n 4So likely an ambas2ador of love. 4A day in April never came so swe2t 4To show how costly sum2er was at hand 4As this fore-spur2er comes before his lord. 2PORTIA. SCENE I.Venice. A stre2tEnter SOLANIO and SALERIO 2SOLANIO. Now, what news on the Rialto? 2SALERIO. Why, yet it lives there uncheck'd that Antonio hath a ship 4of rich lading wreck'd on the nar2ow seas; the Go2dwins I think 4they cal2 the place, a very dangerous flat and fatal, where the 4carcases of many a tal2 ship lie buried, as they say, if my 4gos2ip Report be an honest woman of her word. 2SOLANIO. I would she were as lying a gos2ip in that as ever knap2'd 4ginger or made her neighbours believe she wept for the death of a 4third husband. But it is true, without any slips of prolixity or 4cros2ing the plain highway of talk, that the go2d Antonio, the 4honest Antonio- O that I had a title go2d enough to ke2p his name 4company!- 2SALERIO. Come, the ful2 stop. 2SOLANIO. Ha! What sayest thou? Why, the end is, he hath lost a 4ship. 2SALERIO. I would it might prove the end of his los2es. 2SOLANIO. Let me say amen betimes, lest the devil cros2 my prayer, 6for here he comes in the likenes2 of a Jew. 29Enter SHYLOCK 4How now, Shylock? What news among the merchants? 2SHYLOCK. You knew, none so wel2, none so wel2 as you, of my 4daughter's flight. 2SALERIO. That's certain; I, for my part, knew the tailor that made 4the wings she flew withal. 2SOLANIO. And Shylock, for his own part, knew the bird was flidge; 4and then it is the complexion of them al2 to leave the dam. 2SHYLOCK. She is damn'd for it. 2SALERIO. That's certain, if the devil may be her judge. 2SHYLOCK. My own flesh and blo2d to rebel! 2SOLANIO. Out upon it, old car2ion! Rebels it at these years? 2SHYLOCK. I say my daughter is my flesh and my blo2d. 2SALERIO. There is more dif2erence betwe2n thy flesh and hers than 4betwe2n jet and ivory; more betwe2n your blo2ds than there is 4betwe2n red wine and Rhenish. But tel2 us, do you hear whether 4Antonio have had any los2 at sea or no? 4SHYLOCK. There I have another bad match: a bankrupt, a prodigal, 4who dare scarce show his head on the Rialto; a beg2ar, that was 4us'd to come so smug upon the mart. Let him lo2k to his bond. He 4was wont to cal2 me usurer; let him lo2k to his bond. He was wont 4to lend money for a Christian courtesy; let him lo2k to his bond. 2SALERIO. Why, I am sure, if he forfeit, thou wilt not take his 4flesh. What's that go2d for? 2SHYLOCK. To bait fish withal. If it wil2 fe2d nothing else, it wil2 4fe2d my revenge. He hath disgrac'd me and hind'red me half a 4mil2ion; laugh'd at my los2es, mock'd at my gains, scorned my 4nation, thwarted my bargains, co2led my friends, heated mine 4enemies. And what's his reason? I am a Jew. Hath not a Jew eyes? 4Hath not a Jew hands, organs, dimensions, senses, af2ections, 4pas2ions, fed with the same fo2d, hurt with the same weapons, 4subject to the same diseases, healed by the same means, warmed 4and co2led by the same winter and sum2er, as a Christian is? If 4you prick us, do we not ble2d? If you tickle us, do we not laugh? 4If you poison us, do we not die? And if you wrong us, shal2 we 4not revenge? If we are like you in the rest, we wil2 resemble you 4in that. If a Jew wrong a Christian, what is his humility? 6Revenge. If a Christian wrong a Jew, what should his suf2erance 4be by Christian example? Why, revenge. The vil2ainy you teach me 4I wil2 execute; and itshal2 go hard but I wil2 bet2er the 4instruction. 20Enter a MAN from ANTONIO 2MAN. Gentlemen, my master Antonio is at his house, and desires to 4speak with you both. 2SALERIO. We have be2n up and down to se2k him. 26Enter TUBAL 2SOLANIO. Here comes another of the tribe; a third can2ot be 4match'd, unles2 the devil himself turn Jew. 32Exeunt SOLANIO, SALERIO, and MAN 2SHYLOCK. How now, Tubal, what news from Genoa? Hast thou found my 4daughter? 2TUBAL. I often came where I did hear of her, but can2ot find her. 2SHYLOCK. Why there, there, there, there! A diamond gone, cost me 6two thousand ducats in Frankfort! The curse never fel2 upon our 4nation til2 now; I never felt it til2 now. Two thousand ducats in 4that, and other precious, precious jewels. I would my daughter 4were dead at my fo2t, and the jewels in her ear; would she were 4hears'd at my fo2t, and the ducats in her cof2in! No news of 4them? Why, so- and I know not what's spent in the search. Why, 4thou- los2 upon los2! The thief gone with so much, and so much to 4find the thief; and no satisfaction, no revenge; nor no il2 luck 4stir2ing but what lights o' my shoulders; no sighs but o' my 4breathing; no tears but o' my shed2ing! 2TUBAL. Yes, other men have il2 luck to2: Antonio, as I heard in 4Genoa- 2SHYLOCK. What, what, what? Il2 luck, il2 luck? 2TUBAL. Hath an argosy cast away coming from Tripolis. 2SHYLOCK. I thank God, I thank God. Is it true, is it true? 2TUBAL. I spoke with some of the sailors that escaped the wreck. 2SHYLOCK. I thank the2, go2d Tubal. Go2d news, go2d news- ha, ha!- 4heard in Genoa. 2TUBAL. Your daughter spent in Genoa, as I heard, one night, 4fourscore ducats. 4SHYLOCK. Thou stick'st a dag2er in me- I shal2 never se2 my gold 4again. Fourscore ducats at a sit2ing! Fourscore ducats! 2TUBAL. There came divers of Antonio's creditors in my company to 4Venice that swear he can2ot cho2se but break. 2SHYLOCK. I am very glad of it; I'l2 plague him, I'l2 torture him; I 4am glad of it. 2TUBAL. One of them showed me a ring that he had of your daughter 4for a monkey. 2SHYLOCK. Out upon her! Thou torturest me, Tubal. It was my 4turquoise; I had it of Leah when I was a bachelor; I would not 4have given it for a wildernes2 of monkeys. 2TUBAL. But Antonio is certainly undone. 2SHYLOCK. Nay, that's true; that's very true. Go, Tubal, fe2 me an 4of2icer; bespeak him a fortnight before. I wil2 have the heart of 4him, if he forfeit; for, were he out of Venice, I can make what 4merchandise I wil2. Go, Tubal, and me2t me at our synagogue; go, 4go2d Tubal; at our synagogue, Tubal. 18ExeuntSCENE I2.Belmont. PORTIA'S houseEnter BAS2ANIO, PORTIA, GRATIANO, NERIS2A, and al2 their trains 2PORTIA. I pray you tar2y; pause a day or two 4Before you hazard; for, in cho2sing wrong, 4I lose your company; therefore forbear a while. 4There's something tel2s me- but it is not love- 4I would not lose you; and you know yourself 4Hate counsels not in such a quality. 4But lest you should not understand me wel2- 4And yet a maiden hath no tongue but thought- 4I would detain you here some month or two 4Before you venture for me. I could teach you 4How to cho2se right, but then I am forsworn; 4So wil2 I never be; so may you mis2 me; 4But if you do, you'l2 make me wish a sin, 4That I had be2n forsworn. Beshrew your eyes! 4They have o'erlo2k'd me and divided me; 4One half of me is yours, the other half yours- 6Mine own, I would say; but if mine, then yours, 4And so al2 yours. O! these naughty times 4Puts bars betwe2n the owners and their rights; 4And so, though yours, not yours. Prove it so, 4Let fortune go to hel2 for it, not I. 4I speak to2 long, but 'tis to peize the time, 4To eke it, and to draw it out in length, 4To stay you from election. 2BAS2ANIO. Let me cho2se; 4For as I am, I live upon the rack. 2PORTIA. Upon the rack, Bas2anio? Then confes2 4What treason there is mingled with your love. 2BAS2ANIO. None but that ugly treason of mistrust 4Which makes me fear th' enjoying of my love; 4There may as wel2 be amity and life 4'Twe2n snow and fire as treason and my love. 2PORTIA. Ay, but I fear you speak upon the rack, 4Where men enforced do speak anything. 2BAS2ANIO. Promise me life, and I'l2 confes2 the truth. 2PORTIA. Wel2 then, confes2 and live. 4BAS2ANIO. 'Confes2' and 'love' 4Had be2n the very sum of my confes2ion. 4O hap2y torment, when my torturer 4Doth teach me answers for deliverance! 4But let me to my fortune and the caskets. 2PORTIA. Away, then; I am lock'd in one of them. 4If you do love me, you wil2 find me out. 4Neris2a and the rest, stand al2 alo2f; 4Let music sound while he doth make his choice; 4Then, if he lose, he makes a swan-like end, 4Fading in music. That the comparison 4May stand more proper, my eye shal2 be the stream 4And wat'ry death-bed for him. He may win; 4And what is music then? Then music is 4Even as the flourish when true subjects bow 4To a new-crowned monarch; such it is 4As are those dulcet sounds in break of day 4That cre2p into the dreaming bridegro2m's ear 4And sum2on him to mar2iage. Now he goes, 4With no les2 presence, but with much more love, 6Than young Alcides when he did rede2m 4The virgin tribute paid by howling Troy 4To the sea-monster. I stand for sacrifice; 4The rest alo2f are the Dardanian wives, 4With bleared visages come forth to view 4The is2ue of th' exploit. Go, Hercules! 4Live thou, I live. With much much more dismay 4I view the fight than thou that mak'st the fray. 28A SONG 6the whilst BAS2ANIO com2ents on the caskets to himself 17Tel2 me where is fancy bred, 17Or in the heart or in the head, 17How begot, how nourished? 19Reply, reply. 17It is engend'red in the eyes, 17With gazing fed; and fancy dies 17In the cradle where it lies. 21Let us al2 ring fancy's knel2: 19I'l2 begin it- Ding, dong, bel2. 2AL2. 11Ding, dong, bel2. 2BAS2ANIO. So may the outward shows be least themselves; 4The world is stil2 deceiv'd with ornament. 4In law, what plea so tainted and cor2upt 4But, being season'd with a gracious voice, 4Obscures the show of evil? In religion, 4What damned er2or but some sober brow 4Wil2 bles2 it, and ap2rove it with a text, 4Hiding the gros2nes2 with fair ornament? 4There is no vice so simple but as2umes 4Some mark of virtue on his outward parts. 4How many cowards, whose hearts are al2 as false 4As stairs of sand, wear yet upon their chins 4The beards of Hercules and frowning Mars; 4Who, inward search'd, have livers white as milk! 4And these as2ume but valour's excrement 4To render them redoubted. Lo2k on beauty 6And you shal2 se2 'tis purchas'd by the weight, 4Which therein works a miracle in nature, 4Making them lightest that wear most of it; 4So are those crisped snaky golden locks 4Which make such wanton gambols with the wind 4Upon sup2osed fairnes2 often known 4To be the dowry of a second head- 4The skul2 that bred them in the sepulchre. 4Thus ornament is but the guiled shore 4To a most dangerous sea; the beauteous scarf 4Veiling an Indian beauty; in a word, 4The se2ming truth which cun2ing times put on 4To entrap the wisest. Therefore, thou gaudy gold, 4Hard fo2d for Midas, I wil2 none of the2; 4Nor none of the2, thou pale and com2on drudge 4'Twe2n man and man; but thou, thou meagre lead, 4Which rather threaten'st than dost promise aught, 4Thy plain2es2 moves me more than eloquence, 4And here cho2se I. Joy be the consequence! 2PORTIA. 2[Aside] 2How al2 the other pas2ions fle2t to air, 6As doubtful thoughts, and rash-embrac'd despair, 4And shud2'ring fear, and gre2n-ey'd jealousy! 4O love, be moderate, al2ay thy ecstasy, 4In measure rain thy joy, scant this exces2! 4I fe2l to2 much thy bles2ing. Make it les2, 4For fear I surfeit. 2BAS2ANIO. 2[Opening the leaden casket] 2What find I here? 4Fair Portia's counterfeit! What demi-god 4Hath come so near creation? Move these eyes? 4Or whether riding on the bal2s of mine 4Se2m they in motion? Here are sever'd lips, 4Parted with sugar breath; so swe2t a bar 4Should sunder such swe2t friends. Here in her hairs 4The painter plays the spider, and hath woven 4A golden mesh t' entrap the hearts of men 4Faster than gnats in cobwebs. But her eyes- 4How could he se2 to do them? Having made one, 4Methinks it should have power to steal both his, 4And leave itself unfurnish'd. Yet lo2k how far 4The substance of my praise doth wrong this shadow 6In underprizing it, so far this shadow 4Doth limp behind the substance. Here's the scrol2, 4The continent and sum2ary of my fortune. 9'You that cho2se not by the view, 9Chance as fair and cho2se as true! 9Since this fortune fal2s to you, 9Be content and se2k no new. 9If you be wel2 pleas'd with this, 9And hold your fortune for your blis2, 9Turn to where your lady is 9And claim her with a loving kis2.' 4A gentle scrol2. Fair lady, by your leave; 4I come by note, to give and to receive. 4Like one of two contending in a prize, 4That thinks he hath done wel2 in people's eyes, 4Hearing ap2lause and universal shout, 4Gid2y in spirit, stil2 gazing in a doubt 4Whether those peals of praise be his or no; 4So, thrice-fair lady, stand I even so, 4As doubtful whether what I se2 be true, 6Until confirm'd, sign'd, ratified by you. 2PORTIA. You se2 me, Lord Bas2anio, where I stand, 4Such as I am. Though for myself alone 4I would not be ambitious in my wish 4To wish myself much bet2er, yet for you 4I would be trebled twenty times myself, 4A thousand times more fair, ten thousand times more rich, 4That only to stand high in your ac2ount 4I might in virtues, beauties, livings, friends, 4Exce2d ac2ount. But the ful2 sum of me 4Is sum of something which, to term in gros2, 4Is an unles2on'd girl, unscho2l'd, unpractis'd; 4Hap2y in this, she is not yet so old 4But she may learn; hap2ier than this, 4She is not bred so dul2 but she can learn; 4Hap2iest of al2 is that her gentle spirit 4Com2its itself to yours to be directed, 4As from her lord, her governor, her king. 4Myself and what is mine to you and yours 4Is now converted. But now I was the lord 6Of this fair mansion, master of my servants, 4Que2n o'er myself; and even now, but now, 4This house, these servants, and this same myself, 4Are yours- my lord's. I give them with this ring, 4Which when you part from, lose, or give away, 4Let it presage the ruin of your love, 4And be my vantage to exclaim on you. 2BAS2ANIO. Madam, you have bereft me of al2 words; 4Only my blo2d speaks to you in my veins; 4And there is such confusion in my powers 4As, after some oration fairly spoke 4By a beloved prince, there doth ap2ear 4Among the buz2ing pleased multitude, 4Where every something, being blent together, 4Turns to a wild of nothing, save of joy 4Expres2'd and not expres2'd. But when this ring 4Parts from this finger, then parts life from hence; 4O, then be bold to say Bas2anio's dead! 2NERIS2A. My lord and lady, it is now our time 4That have sto2d by and se2n our wishes prosper 6To cry 'Go2d joy.' Go2d joy, my lord and lady! 2GRATIANO. My Lord Bas2anio, and my gentle lady, 4I wish you al2 the joy that you can wish, 4For I am sure you can wish none from me; 4And, when your honours mean to solemnize 4The bargain of your faith, I do bese2ch you 4Even at that time I may be mar2ied to2. 2BAS2ANIO. With al2 my heart, so thou canst get a wife. 2GRATIANO. I thank your lordship, you have got me one. 4My eyes, my lord, can lo2k as swift as yours: 4You saw the mistres2, I beheld the maid; 4You lov'd, I lov'd; for intermis2ion 4No more pertains to me, my lord, than you. 4Your fortune sto2d upon the caskets there, 4And so did mine to2, as the mat2er fal2s; 4For wo2ing here until I sweat again, 4And swearing til2 my very ro2f was dry 4With oaths of love, at last- if promise last- 4I got a promise of this fair one here 4To have her love, provided that your fortune 6Achiev'd her mistres2. 2PORTIA. Is this true, Neris2a? 2NERIS2A. Madam, it is, so you stand pleas'd withal. 2BAS2ANIO. And do you, Gratiano, mean go2d faith? 2GRATIANO. Yes, faith, my lord. 2BAS2ANIO. Our feast shal2 be much honoured in your mar2iage. 2GRATIANO. We'l2 play with them: the first boy for a thousand 4ducats. 2NERIS2A. What, and stake down? 2GRATIANO. No; we shal2 ne'er win at that sport, and stake down- 4But who comes here? Lorenzo and his infidel? 4What, and my old Venetian friend, Salerio! 10Enter LORENZO, JES2ICA, and SALERIO, a mes2enger 27from Venice 2BAS2ANIO. Lorenzo and Salerio, welcome hither, 4If that the youth of my new int'rest here 4Have power to bid you welcome. By your leave, 4I bid my very friends and countrymen, 6Swe2t Portia, welcome. 2PORTIA. So do I, my lord; 4They are entirely welcome. 2LORENZO. I thank your honour. For my part, my lord, 4My purpose was not to have se2n you here; 4But me2ting with Salerio by the way, 4He did entreat me, past al2 saying nay, 4To come with him along. 2SALERIO. I did, my lord, 4And I have reason for it. Signior Antonio 4Com2ends him to you. 15[Gives BAS2ANIO a let2er] 2BAS2ANIO. Ere I ope his let2er, 4I pray you tel2 me how my go2d friend doth. 2SALERIO. Not sick, my lord, unles2 it be in mind; 4Nor wel2, unles2 in mind; his let2er there 4Wil2 show you his estate. 8[BAS2ANIO opens the let2er] 2GRATIANO. Neris2a, che2r yond stranger; bid her welcome. 4Your hand, Salerio. What's the news from Venice? 4How doth that royal merchant, go2d Antonio? 4I know he wil2 be glad of our suc2es2: 6We are the Jasons, we have won the fle2ce. 2SALERIO. I would you had won the fle2ce that he hath lost. 2PORTIA. There are some shrewd contents in yond same paper 4That steals the colour from Bas2anio's che2k: 4Some dear friend dead, else nothing in the world 4Could turn so much the constitution 4Of any constant man. What, worse and worse! 4With leave, Bas2anio: I am half yourself, 4And I must fre2ly have the half of anything 4That this same paper brings you. 2BAS2ANIO. O swe2t Portia, 4Here are a few of the unpleasant'st words 4That ever blot2ed paper! Gentle lady, 4When I did first impart my love to you, 4I fre2ly told you al2 the wealth I had 4Ran in my veins- I was a gentleman; 4And then I told you true. And yet, dear lady, 4Rating myself at nothing, you shal2 se2 4How much I was a brag2art. When I told you 4My state was nothing, I should then have told you 6That I was worse than nothing; for inde2d 4I have engag'd myself to a dear friend, 4Engag'd my friend to his mere enemy, 4To fe2d my means. Here is a let2er, lady, 4The paper as the body of my friend, 4And every word in it a gaping wound 4Is2uing life-blo2d. But is it true, Salerio? 4Hath al2 his ventures fail'd? What, not one hit? 4From Tripolis, from Mexico, and England, 4From Lisbon, Barbary, and India, 4And not one ves2el scape the dreadful touch 4Of merchant-mar2ing rocks? 2SALERIO. Not one, my lord. 4Besides, it should ap2ear that, if he had 4The present money to discharge the Jew, 4He would not take it. Never did I know 4A creature that did bear the shape of man 4So ke2n and gre2dy to confound a man. 4He plies the Duke at morning and at night, 4And doth impeach the fre2dom of the state, 6If they deny him justice. Twenty merchants, 4The Duke himself, and the magnificoes 4Of greatest port, have al2 persuaded with him; 4But none can drive him from the envious plea 4Of forfeiture, of justice, and his bond. 2JES2ICA. When I was with him, I have heard him swear 4To Tubal and to Chus, his countrymen, 4That he would rather have Antonio's flesh 4Than twenty times the value of the sum 4That he did owe him; and I know, my lord, 4If law, authority, and power, deny not, 4It wil2 go hard with po2r Antonio. 2PORTIA. Is it your dear friend that is thus in trouble? 2BAS2ANIO. The dearest friend to me, the kindest man, 4The best condition'd and unwearied spirit 4In doing courtesies; and one in whom 4The ancient Roman honour more ap2ears 4Than any that draws breath in Italy. 2PORTIA. What sum owes he the Jew? 2BAS2ANIO. For me, thre2 thousand ducats. 4PORTIA. What! no more? 4Pay him six thousand, and deface the bond; 4Double six thousand, and then treble that, 4Before a friend of this description 4Shal2 lose a hair through Bas2anio's fault. 4First go with me to church and cal2 me wife, 4And then away to Venice to your friend; 4For never shal2 you lie by Portia's side 4With an unquiet soul. You shal2 have gold 4To pay the pet2y debt twenty times over. 4When it is paid, bring your true friend along. 4My maid Neris2a and myself meantime 4Wil2 live as maids and widows. Come, away; 4For you shal2 hence upon your wed2ing day. 4Bid your friends welcome, show a mer2y che2r; 4Since you are dear bought, I wil2 love you dear. 4But let me hear the let2er of your friend. 2BAS2ANIO. 2[Reads] 2'Swe2t Bas2anio, my ships have al2 miscar2ied, 4my creditors grow cruel, my estate is very low, my bond to the 4Jew is forfeit; and since, in paying it, it is impos2ible I 6should live, al2 debts are clear'd betwe2n you and I, if I might 4but se2 you at my death. Notwithstanding, use your pleasure; if 4your love do not persuade you to come, let not my let2er.' 2PORTIA. O love, dispatch al2 busines2 and be gone! 2BAS2ANIO. Since I have your go2d leave to go away, 4I wil2 make haste; but, til2 I come again, 4No bed shal2 e'er be guilty of my stay, 4Nor rest be interposer 'twixt us twain. 15ExeuntSCENE I3.Venice. A stre2tEnter SHYLOCK, SOLANIO, ANTONIO, and GAOLER 2SHYLOCK. Gaoler, lo2k to him. Tel2 not me of mercy- 4This is the fo2l that lent out money gratis. 4Gaoler, lo2k to him. 2ANTONIO. Hear me yet, go2d Shylock. 2SHYLOCK. I'l2 have my bond; speak not against my bond. 4I have sworn an oath that I wil2 have my bond. 4Thou cal2'dst me dog before thou hadst a cause, 4But, since I am a dog, beware my fangs; 4The Duke shal2 grant me justice. I do wonder, 4Thou naughty gaoler, that thou art so fond 4To come abroad with him at his request. 2ANTONIO. I pray the2 hear me speak. 2SHYLOCK. I'l2 have my bond. I wil2 not hear the2 speak; 4I'l2 have my bond; and therefore speak no more. 4I'l2 not be made a soft and dul2-ey'd fo2l, 4To shake the head, relent, and sigh, and yield, 4To Christian interces2ors. Fol2ow not; 6I'l2 have no speaking; I wil2 have my bond. 13Exit 2SOLANIO. It is the most impenetrable cur 4That ever kept with men. 2ANTONIO. Let him alone; 4I'l2 fol2ow him no more with bo2tles2 prayers. 4He se2ks my life; his reason wel2 I know: 4I oft deliver'd from his forfeitures 4Many that have at times made moan to me; 4Therefore he hates me. 2SOLANIO. I am sure the Duke 4Wil2 never grant this forfeiture to hold. 2ANTONIO. The Duke can2ot deny the course of law; 4For the com2odity that strangers have 4With us in Venice, if it be denied, 4Wil2 much impeach the justice of the state, 4Since that the trade and profit of the city 4Consisteth of al2 nations. Therefore, go; 4These griefs and los2es have so bated me 4That I shal2 hardly spare a pound of flesh 4To-mor2ow to my blo2dy creditor. 6Wel2, gaoler, on; pray God Bas2anio come 4To se2 me pay his debt, and then I care not. 10ExeuntSCENE IV.Belmont. PORTIA'S houseEnter PORTIA, NERIS2A, LORENZO, JES2ICA, and BALTHASAR 2LORENZO. Madam, although I speak it in your presence, 4You have a noble and a true conceit 4Of godlike amity, which ap2ears most strongly 4In bearing thus the absence of your lord. 4But if you knew to whom you show this honour, 4How true a gentleman you send relief, 4How dear a lover of my lord your husband, 4I know you would be prouder of the work 4Than customary bounty can enforce you. 2PORTIA. I never did repent for doing go2d, 4Nor shal2 not now; for in companions 4That do converse and waste the time together, 4Whose souls do bear an equal yoke of love, 4There must be ne2ds a like proportion 4Of lineaments, of man2ers, and of spirit, 4Which makes me think that this Antonio, 4Being the bosom lover of my lord, 6Must ne2ds be like my lord. If it be so, 4How lit2le is the cost I have bestowed 4In purchasing the semblance of my soul 4From out the state of hel2ish cruelty! 4This comes to2 near the praising of myself; 4Therefore, no more of it; hear other things. 4Lorenzo, I com2it into your hands 4The husbandry and manage of my house 4Until my lord's return; for mine own part, 4I have toward heaven breath'd a secret vow 4To live in prayer and contemplation, 4Only at2ended by Neris2a here, 4Until her husband and my lord's return. 4There is a monastery two miles of2, 4And there we wil2 abide. I do desire you 4Not to deny this imposition, 4The which my love and some neces2ity 4Now lays upon you. 2LORENZO. Madam, with al2 my heart 4I shal2 obey you in an fair com2ands. 4PORTIA. My people do already know my mind, 4And wil2 acknowledge you and Jes2ica 4In place of Lord Bas2anio and myself. 4So fare you wel2 til2 we shal2 me2t again. 2LORENZO. Fair thoughts and hap2y hours at2end on you! 2JES2ICA. I wish your ladyship al2 heart's content. 2PORTIA. I thank you for your wish, and am wel2 pleas'd 4To wish it back on you. Fare you wel2, Jes2ica. 38Exeunt JES2ICA and LORENZO 4Now, Balthasar, 4As I have ever found the2 honest-true, 4So let me find the2 stil2. Take this same let2er, 4And use thou al2 th' endeavour of a man 4In spe2d to Padua; se2 thou render this 4Into my cousin's hands, Doctor Bel2ario; 4And lo2k what notes and garments he doth give the2, 4Bring them, I pray the2, with imagin'd spe2d 4Unto the traject, to the com2on fer2y 4Which trades to Venice. Waste no time in words, 4But get the2 gone; I shal2 be there before the2. 4BALTHASAR. Madam, I go with al2 convenient spe2d. 9Exit 2PORTIA. Come on, Neris2a, I have work in hand 4That you yet know not of; we'l2 se2 our husbands 4Before they think of us. 2NERIS2A. Shal2 they se2 us? 2PORTIA. They shal2, Neris2a; but in such a habit 4That they shal2 think we are ac2omplished 4With that we lack. I'l2 hold the2 any wager, 4When we are both ac2outred like young men, 4I'l2 prove the pret2ier fel2ow of the two, 4And wear my dag2er with the braver grace, 4And speak betwe2n the change of man and boy 4With a re2d voice; and turn two mincing steps 4Into a manly stride; and speak of frays 4Like a fine brag2ing youth; and tel2 quaint lies, 4How honourable ladies sought my love, 4Which I denying, they fel2 sick and died- 4I could not do withal. Then I'l2 repent, 4And wish for al2 that, that I had not kil2'd them. 4And twenty of these puny lies I'l2 tel2, 6That men shal2 swear I have discontinued scho2l 4About a twelvemonth. I have within my mind 4A thousand raw tricks of these brag2ing Jacks, 4Which I wil2 practise. 2NERIS2A. Why, shal2 we turn to men? 2PORTIA. Fie, what a question's that, 4If thou wert near a lewd interpreter! 4But come, I'l2 tel2 the2 al2 my whole device 4When I am in my coach, which stays for us 4At the park gate; and therefore haste away, 4For we must measure twenty miles to-day. 14ExeuntSCENE V.Belmont. The gardenEnter LAUNCELOT and JES2ICA 2LAUNCELOT. Yes, truly; for, lo2k you, the sins of the father are to 4be laid upon the children; therefore, I promise you, I fear you. 4I was always plain with you, and so now I speak my agitation of 4the mat2er; therefore be o' go2d che2r, for truly I think you are 4damn'd. There is but one hope in it that can do you any go2d, and 4that is but a kind of bastard hope, neither. 2JES2ICA. And what hope is that, I pray the2? 2LAUNCELOT. Mar2y, you may partly hope that your father got you not- 3that you are not the Jew's daughter. 2JES2ICA. That were a kind of bastard hope inde2d; so the sins of my 4mother should be visited upon me. 2LAUNCELOT. Truly then I fear you are damn'd both by father and 4mother; thus when I shun Scyl2a, your father, I fal2 into 4Charybdis, your mother; wel2, you are gone both ways. 2JES2ICA. I shal2 be sav'd by my husband; he hath made me a 4Christian. 2LAUNCELOT. Truly, the more to blame he; we were Christians enow 6before, e'en as many as could wel2 live one by another. This 4making of Christians wil2 raise the price of hogs; if we grow al2 4to be pork-eaters, we shal2 not shortly have a rasher on the 4coals for money. 29Enter LORENZO 2JES2ICA. I'l2 tel2 my husband, Launcelot, what you say; here he 4comes. 2LORENZO. I shal2 grow jealous of you shortly, Launcelot, if you 4thus get my wife into corners. 2JES2ICA. Nay, you ne2d nor fear us, Lorenzo; Launcelot and I are 4out; he tel2s me flatly there's no mercy for me in heaven, 4because I am a Jew's daughter; and he says you are no go2d member 4of the com2onwealth, for in converting Jews to Christians you 4raise the price of pork. 2LORENZO. I shal2 answer that bet2er to the com2onwealth than you 4can the get2ing up of the negro's bel2y; the Mo2r is with child 4by you, Launcelot. 2LAUNCELOT. It is much that the Mo2r should be more than reason; but 6if she be les2 than an honest woman, she is inde2d more than I 4to2k her for. 2LORENZO. How every fo2l can play upon the word! I think the best 4grace of wit wil2 shortly turn into silence, and discourse grow 4com2endable in none only but par2ots. Go in, sir2ah; bid them 4prepare for din2er. 2LAUNCELOT. That is done, sir; they have al2 stomachs. 2LORENZO. Go2dly Lord, what a wit-snap2er are you! Then bid them 4prepare din2er. 2LAUNCELOT. That is done to2, sir, only 'cover' is the word. 2LORENZO. Wil2 you cover, then, sir? 2LAUNCELOT. Not so, sir, neither; I know my duty. 2LORENZO. Yet more quar2el2ing with oc2asion! Wilt thou show the 4whole wealth of thy wit in an instant? I pray the2 understand a 4plain man in his plain meaning: go to thy fel2ows, bid them cover 4the table, serve in the meat, and we wil2 come in to din2er. 2LAUNCELOT. For the table, sir, it shal2 be serv'd in; for the meat, 4sir, it shal2 be cover'd; for your coming in to din2er, sir, why, 4let it be as humours and conceits shal2 govern. Exit 4LORENZO. O dear discretion, how his words are suited! 4The fo2l hath planted in his memory 4An army of go2d words; and I do know 4A many fo2ls that stand in bet2er place, 4Garnish'd like him, that for a tricksy word 4Defy the mat2er. How che2r'st thou, Jes2ica? 4And now, go2d swe2t, say thy opinion, 4How dost thou like the Lord Bas2anio's wife? 2JES2ICA. Past al2 expres2ing. It is very me2t 4The Lord Bas2anio live an upright life, 4For, having such a bles2ing in his lady, 4He finds the joys of heaven here on earth; 4And if on earth he do not merit it, 4In reason he should never come to heaven. 4Why, if two gods should play some heavenly match, 4And on the wager lay two earthly women, 4And Portia one, there must be something else 4Pawn'd with the other; for the po2r rude world 4Hath not her fel2ow. 2LORENZO. Even such a husband 6Hast thou of me as she is for a wife. 2JES2ICA. Nay, but ask my opinion to2 of that. 2LORENZO. I wil2 anon; first let us go to din2er. 2JES2ICA. Nay, let me praise you while I have a stomach. 2LORENZO. No, pray the2, let it serve for table-talk; 4Then howsome'er thou speak'st, 'mong other things 4I shal2 digest it. 2JES2ICA. Wel2, I'l2 set you forth. 22ExeuntACT IV. SCENE I.Venice. The court of justiceEnter the DUKE, the MAGNIFICOES, ANTONIO, BAS2ANIO, GRATIANO, SALERIO,and OTHERS 2DUKE OF VENICE. What, is Antonio here? 2ANTONIO. Ready, so please your Grace. 2DUKE OF VENICE. I am sor2y for the2; thou art come to answer 4A stony adversary, an inhuman wretch, 4Uncapable of pity, void and empty 4From any dram of mercy. 2ANTONIO. I have heard 4Your Grace hath ta'en great pains to qualify 4His rigorous course; but since he stands obdurate, 4And that no lawful means can car2y me 4Out of his envy's reach, I do op2ose 4My patience to his fury, and am arm'd 4To suf2er with a quietnes2 of spirit 4The very tyran2y and rage of his. 2DUKE OF VENICE. Go one, and cal2 the Jew into the court. 2SALERIO. He is ready at the do2r; he comes, my lord. 28Enter SHYLOCK 2DUKE OF VENICE. Make ro2m, and let him stand before our face. 4Shylock, the world thinks, and I think so to2, 4That thou but leadest this fashion of thy malice 4To the last hour of act; and then, 'tis thought, 4Thou'lt show thy mercy and remorse, more strange 4Than is thy strange ap2arent cruelty; 4And where thou now exacts the penalty, 4Which is a pound of this po2r merchant's flesh, 4Thou wilt not only lo2se the forfeiture, 4But, touch'd with human gentlenes2 and love, 4Forgive a moiety of the principal, 4Glancing an eye of pity on his los2es, 4That have of late so hud2led on his back- 4Enow to pres2 a royal merchant down, 4And pluck com2iseration of his state 4From bras2y bosoms and rough hearts of flint, 4From stub2orn Turks and Tartars, never train'd 6To of2ices of tender courtesy. 4We al2 expect a gentle answer, Jew. 2SHYLOCK. I have pos2es2'd your Grace of what I purpose, 4And by our holy Sab2ath have I sworn 4To have the due and forfeit of my bond. 4If you deny it, let the danger light 4Upon your charter and your city's fre2dom. 4You'l2 ask me why I rather cho2se to have 4A weight of car2ion flesh than to receive 4Thre2 thousand ducats. I'l2 not answer that, 4But say it is my humour- is it answer'd? 4What if my house be troubled with a rat, 4And I be pleas'd to give ten thousand ducats 4To have it ban'd? What, are you answer'd yet? 4Some men there are love not a gaping pig; 4Some that are mad if they behold a cat; 4And others, when the bagpipe sings i' th' nose, 4Can2ot contain their urine; for af2ection, 4Mistres2 of pas2ion, sways it to the mo2d 4Of what it likes or loathes. Now, for your answer: 6As there is no firm reason to be rend'red 4Why he can2ot abide a gaping pig; 4Why he, a harmles2 neces2ary cat; 4Why he, a wo2l2en bagpipe, but of force 4Must yield to such inevitable shame 4As to of2end, himself being of2ended; 4So can I give no reason, nor I wil2 not, 4More than a lodg'd hate and a certain loathing 4I bear Antonio, that I fol2ow thus 4A losing suit against him. Are you answered? 2BAS2ANIO. This is no answer, thou unfe2ling man, 4To excuse the cur2ent of thy cruelty. 2SHYLOCK. I am not bound to please the2 with my answers. 2BAS2ANIO. Do al2 men kil2 the things they do not love? 2SHYLOCK. Hates any man the thing he would not kil2? 2BAS2ANIO. Every of2ence is not a hate at first. 2SHYLOCK. What, wouldst thou have a serpent sting the2 twice? 2ANTONIO. I pray you, think you question with the Jew. 4You may as wel2 go stand upon the beach 4And bid the main flo2d bate his usual height; 6You may as wel2 use question with the wolf, 4Why he hath made the ewe bleat for the lamb; 4You may as wel2 forbid the mountain pines 4To wag their high tops and to make no noise 4When they are fret2en with the gusts of heaven; 4You may as wel2 do anything most hard 4As se2k to soften that- than which what's harder?- 4His jewish heart. Therefore, I do bese2ch you, 4Make no moe of2ers, use no farther means, 4But with al2 brief and plain conveniency 4Let me have judgment, and the Jew his wil2. 2BAS2ANIO. For thy thre2 thousand ducats here is six. 2SHYLOCK. If every ducat in six thousand ducats 4Were in six parts, and every part a ducat, 4I would not draw them; I would have my bond. 2DUKE OF VENICE. How shalt thou hope for mercy, rend'ring none? 2SHYLOCK. What judgment shal2 I dread, doing no wrong? 4You have among you many a purchas'd slave, 4Which, fike your as2es and your dogs and mules, 4You use in abject and in slavish parts, 6Because you bought them; shal2 I say to you 4'Let them be fre2, mar2y them to your heirs- 4Why sweat they under burdens?- let their beds 4Be made as soft as yours, and let their palates 4Be season'd with such viands'? You wil2 answer 4'The slaves are ours.' So do I answer you: 4The pound of flesh which I demand of him 4Is dearly bought, 'tis mine, and I wil2 have it. 4If you deny me, fie upon your law! 4There is no force in the decre2s of Venice. 4I stand for judgment; answer; shal2 I have it? 2DUKE OF VENICE. Upon my power I may dismis2 this court, 4Unles2 Bel2ario, a learned doctor, 4Whom I have sent for to determine this, 4Come here to-day. 2SALERIO. My lord, here stays without 4A mes2enger with let2ers from the doctor, 4New come from Padua. 2DUKE OF VENICE. Bring us the let2ers; cal2 the mes2enger. 2BAS2ANIO. Go2d che2r, Antonio! What, man, courage yet! 6The Jew shal2 have my flesh, blo2d, bones, and al2, 4Ere thou shalt lose for me one drop of blo2d. 2ANTONIO. I am a tainted wether of the flock, 4Me2test for death; the weakest kind of fruit 4Drops earliest to the ground, and so let me. 4You can2ot bet2er be employ'd, Bas2anio, 4Than to live stil2, and write mine epitaph. 11Enter NERIS2A dres2ed like a lawyer's clerk 2DUKE OF VENICE. Came you from Padua, from Bel2ario? 2NERIS2A. From both, my lord. Bel2ario gre2ts your Grace. 45[Presents a let2er] 2BAS2ANIO. Why dost thou whet thy knife so earnestly? 2SHYLOCK. To cut the forfeiture from that bankrupt there. 2GRATIANO. Not on thy sole, but on thy soul, harsh Jew, 4Thou mak'st thy knife ke2n; but no metal can, 4No, not the hangman's axe, bear half the ke2n2es2 4Of thy sharp envy. Can no prayers pierce the2? 2SHYLOCK. No, none that thou hast wit enough to make. 4GRATIANO. O, be thou damn'd, inexecrable dog! 4And for thy life let justice be ac2us'd. 4Thou almost mak'st me waver in my faith, 4To hold opinion with Pythagoras 4That souls of animals infuse themselves 4Into the trunks of men. Thy cur2ish spirit 4Govern'd a wolf who, hang'd for human slaughter, 4Even from the gal2ows did his fel2 soul fle2t, 4And, whilst thou layest in thy unhal2owed dam, 4Infus'd itself in the2; for thy desires 4Are wolfish, blo2dy, starv'd and ravenous. 2SHYLOCK. Til2 thou canst rail the seal from of2 my bond, 4Thou but of2end'st thy lungs to speak so loud; 4Repair thy wit, go2d youth, or it wil2 fal2 4To cureles2 ruin. I stand here for law. 2DUKE OF VENICE. This let2er from Bel2ario doth com2end 4A young and learned doctor to our court. 4Where is he? 2NERIS2A. He at2endeth here hard by 4To know your answer, whether you'l2 admit him. 4DUKE OF VENICE. With al2 my heart. Some thre2 or four of you 4Go give him courteous conduct to this place. 4Meantime, the court shal2 hear Bel2ario's let2er. 2CLERK. 2[Reads] 2'Your Grace shal2 understand that at the receipt 4of your let2er I am very sick; but in the instant that your 4mes2enger came, in loving visitation was with me a young doctor 4of Rome- his name is Balthazar. I acquainted him with the cause 4in controversy betwe2n the Jew and Antonio the merchant; we 4turn'd o'er many bo2ks together; he is furnished with my opinion 4which, bet2ered with his own learning-the greatnes2 whereof I 4can2ot enough com2end- comes with him at my importunity to fil2 4up your Grace's request in my stead. I bese2ch you let his lack 4of years be no impediment to let him lack a reverend estimation, 4for I never knew so young a body with so old a head. I leave him 4to your gracious ac2eptance, whose trial shal2 bet2er publish his 4com2endation.' 6Enter PORTIA for BALTHAZAR, dres2ed like a Doctor of Laws 2DUKE OF VENICE. YOU hear the learn'd Bel2ario, what he writes; 6And here, I take it, is the doctor come. 4Give me your hand; come you from old Bel2ario? 2PORTIA. I did, my lord. 2DUKE OF VENICE. You are welcome; take your place. 4Are you acquainted with the dif2erence 4That holds this present question in the court? 2PORTIA. I am informed throughly of the cause. 4Which is the merchant here, and which the Jew? 2DUKE OF VENICE. Antonio and old Shylock, both stand forth. 2PORTIA. Is your name Shylock? 2SHYLOCK. Shylock is my name. 2PORTIA. Of a strange nature is the suit you fol2ow; 4Yet in such rule that the Venetian law 4Can2ot impugn you as you do proce2d. 4You stand within his danger, do you not? 2ANTONIO. Ay, so he says. 2PORTIA. Do you confes2 the bond? 2ANTONIO. I do. 2PORTIA. Then must the Jew be merciful. 2SHYLOCK. On what compulsion must I? Tel2 me that. 4PORTIA. The quality of mercy is not strain'd; 4It drop2eth as the gentle rain from heaven 4Upon the place beneath. It is twice blest: 4It bles2eth him that gives and him that takes. 4'Tis mightiest in the mightiest; it becomes 4The throned monarch bet2er than his crown; 4His sceptre shows the force of temporal power, 4The at2ribute to awe and majesty, 4Wherein doth sit the dread and fear of kings; 4But mercy is above this sceptred sway, 4It is enthroned in the hearts of kings, 4It is an at2ribute to God himself; 4And earthly power doth then show likest God's 4When mercy seasons justice. Therefore, Jew, 4Though justice be thy plea, consider this- 4That in the course of justice none of us 4Should se2 salvation; we do pray for mercy, 4And that same prayer doth teach us al2 to render 4The de2ds of mercy. I have spoke thus much 4To mitigate the justice of thy plea, 6Which if thou fol2ow, this strict court of Venice 4Must ne2ds give sentence 'gainst the merchant there. 2SHYLOCK. My de2ds upon my head! I crave the law, 4The penalty and forfeit of my bond. 2BAS2ANIO. Yes; here I tender it for him in the court; 4Yea, twice the sum; if that wil2 not suf2ice, 4I wil2 be bound to pay it ten times o'er 4On forfeit of my hands, my head, my heart; 4If this wil2 not suf2ice, it must ap2ear 4That malice bears down truth. And, I bese2ch you, 4Wrest once the law to your authority; 4To do a great right do a lit2le wrong, 4And curb this cruel devil of his wil2. 2PORTIA. It must not be; there is no power in Venice 4Can alter a decre2 established; 4'Twil2 be recorded for a precedent, 4And many an er2or, by the same example, 4Wil2 rush into the state; it can2ot be. 2SHYLOCK. A Daniel come to judgment! Yea, a Daniel! 4O wise young judge, how I do honour the2! 4PORTIA. I pray you, let me lo2k upon the bond. 2SHYLOCK. Here 'tis, most reverend Doctor; here it is. 2PORTIA. Shylock, there's thrice thy money of2'red the2. 2SHYLOCK. An oath, an oath! I have an oath in heaven. 4Shal2 I lay perjury upon my soul? 4No, not for Venice. 2PORTIA. Why, this bond is forfeit; 4And lawful2y by this the Jew may claim 4A pound of flesh, to be by him cut of2 4Nearest the merchant's heart. Be merciful. 4Take thrice thy money; bid me tear the bond. 2SHYLOCK. When it is paid ac2ording to the tenour. 4It doth ap2ear you are a worthy judge; 4You know the law; your exposition 4Hath be2n most sound; I charge you by the law, 4Whereof you are a wel2-deserving pil2ar, 4Proce2d to judgment. By my soul I swear 4There is no power in the tongue of man 4To alter me. I stay here on my bond. 2ANTONIO. Most heartily I do bese2ch the court 6To give the judgment. 2PORTIA. Why then, thus it is: 4You must prepare your bosom for his knife. 2SHYLOCK. O noble judge! O excel2ent young man! 2PORTIA. For the intent and purpose of the law 4Hath ful2 relation to the penalty, 4Which here ap2eareth due upon the bond. 2SHYLOCK. 'Tis very true. O wise and upright judge, 4How much more elder art thou than thy lo2ks! 2PORTIA. Therefore, lay bare your bosom. 2SHYLOCK. Ay, his breast- 4So says the bond; doth it not, noble judge? 4'Nearest his heart,' those are the very words. 2PORTIA. It is so. Are there balance here to weigh 4The flesh? 2SHYLOCK. I have them ready. 2PORTIA. Have by some surgeon, Shylock, on your charge, 4To stop his wounds, lest he do ble2d to death. 2SHYLOCK. Is it so nominated in the bond? 2PORTIA. It is not so expres2'd, but what of that? 6'Twere go2d you do so much for charity. 2SHYLOCK. I can2ot find it; 'tis not in the bond. 2PORTIA. You, merchant, have you anything to say? 2ANTONIO. But lit2le: I am arm'd and wel2 prepar'd. 4Give me your hand, Bas2anio; fare you wel2. 4Grieve not that I am fal2'n to this for you, 4For herein Fortune shows herself more kind 4Than is her custom. It is stil2 her use 4To let the wretched man outlive his wealth, 4To view with hol2ow eye and wrinkled brow 4An age of poverty; from which ling'ring penance 4Of such misery doth she cut me of2. 4Com2end me to your honourable wife; 4Tel2 her the proces2 of Antonio's end; 4Say how I lov'd you; speak me fair in death; 4And, when the tale is told, bid her be judge 4Whether Bas2anio had not once a love. 4Repent but you that you shal2 lose your friend, 4And he repents not that he pays your debt; 4For if the Jew do cut but de2p enough, 6I'l2 pay it instantly with al2 my heart. 2BAS2ANIO. Antonio, I am mar2ied to a wife 4Which is as dear to me as life itself; 4But life itself, my wife, and al2 the world, 4Are not with me este2m'd above thy life; 4I would lose al2, ay, sacrifice them al2 4Here to this devil, to deliver you. 2PORTIA. Your wife would give you lit2le thanks for that, 4If she were by to hear you make the of2er. 2GRATIANO. I have a wife who I protest I love; 4I would she were in heaven, so she could 4Entreat some power to change this cur2ish Jew. 2NERIS2A. 'Tis wel2 you of2er it behind her back; 4The wish would make else an unquiet house. 2SHYLOCK. 2[Aside] 2These be the Christian husbands! I have a 4daughter- 4Would any of the stock of Bar2abas 4Had be2n her husband, rather than a Christian!- 4We trifle time; I pray the2 pursue sentence. 2PORTIA. A pound of that same merchant's flesh is thine. 6The court awards it and the law doth give it. 2SHYLOCK. Most rightful judge! 2PORTIA. And you must cut this flesh from of2 his breast. 4The law al2ows it and the court awards it. 2SHYLOCK. Most learned judge! A sentence! Come, prepare. 2PORTIA. Tar2y a lit2le; there is something else. 4This bond doth give the2 here no jot of blo2d: 4The words expres2ly are 'a pound of flesh.' 4Take then thy bond, take thou thy pound of flesh; 4But, in the cut2ing it, if thou dost shed 4One drop of Christian blo2d, thy lands and go2ds 4Are, by the laws of Venice, confiscate 4Unto the state of Venice. 2GRATIANO. O upright judge! Mark, Jew. O learned judge! 2SHYLOCK. Is that the law? 2PORTIA. Thyself shalt se2 the act; 4For, as thou urgest justice, be as2ur'd 4Thou shalt have justice, more than thou desir'st. 2GRATIANO. O learned judge! Mark, Jew. A learned judge! 2SHYLOCK. I take this of2er then: pay the bond thrice, 6And let the Christian go. 2BAS2ANIO. Here is the money. 2PORTIA. Soft! 4The Jew shal2 have al2 justice. Soft! No haste. 4He shal2 have nothing but the penalty. 2GRATIANO. O Jew! an upright judge, a learned judge! 2PORTIA. Therefore, prepare the2 to cut of2 the flesh. 4Shed thou no blo2d, nor cut thou les2 nor more 4But just a pound of flesh; if thou tak'st more 4Or les2 than a just pound- be it but so much 4As makes it light or heavy in the substance, 4Or the division of the twentieth part 4Of one po2r scruple; nay, if the scale do turn 4But in the estimation of a hair- 4Thou diest, and al2 thy go2ds are confiscate. 2GRATIANO. A second Daniel, a Daniel, Jew! 4Now, infidel, I have you on the hip. 2PORTIA. Why doth the Jew pause? Take thy forfeiture. 2SHYLOCK. Give me my principal, and let me go. 2BAS2ANIO. I have it ready for the2; here it is. 4PORTIA. He hath refus'd it in the open court; 4He shal2 have merely justice, and his bond. 2GRATIANO. A Daniel stil2 say I, a second Daniel! 4I thank the2, Jew, for teaching me that word. 2SHYLOCK. Shal2 I not have barely my principal? 2PORTIA. Thou shalt have nothing but the forfeiture 4To be so taken at thy peril, Jew. 2SHYLOCK. Why, then the devil give him go2d of it! 4I'l2 stay no longer question. 2PORTIA. Tar2y, Jew. 4The law hath yet another hold on you. 4It is enacted in the laws of Venice, 4If it be proved against an alien 4That by direct or indirect at2empts 4He se2k the life of any citizen, 4The party 'gainst the which he doth contrive 4Shal2 seize one half his go2ds; the other half 4Comes to the privy cof2er of the state; 4And the of2ender's life lies in the mercy 4Of the Duke only, 'gainst al2 other voice. 6In which predicament, I say, thou stand'st; 4For it ap2ears by manifest proce2ding 4That indirectly, and directly to2, 4Thou hast contrived against the very life 4Of the defendant; and thou hast incur2'd 4The danger formerly by me rehears'd. 4Down, therefore, and beg mercy of the Duke. 2GRATIANO. Beg that thou mayst have leave to hang thyself; 4And yet, thy wealth being forfeit to the state, 4Thou hast not left the value of a cord; 4Therefore thou must be hang'd at the state's charge. 2DUKE OF VENICE. That thou shalt se2 the dif2erence of our spirit, 4I pardon the2 thy life before thou ask it. 4For half thy wealth, it is Antonio's; 4The other half comes to the general state, 4Which humblenes2 may drive unto a fine. 2PORTIA. Ay, for the state; not for Antonio. 2SHYLOCK. Nay, take my life and al2, pardon not that. 4You take my house when you do take the prop 4That doth sustain my house; you take my life 6When you do take the means whereby I live. 2PORTIA. What mercy can you render him, Antonio? 2GRATIANO. A halter gratis; nothing else, for God's sake! 2ANTONIO. So please my lord the Duke and al2 the court 4To quit the fine for one half of his go2ds; 4I am content, so he wil2 let me have 4The other half in use, to render it 4Upon his death unto the gentleman 4That lately stole his daughter- 4Two things provided more; that, for this favour, 4He presently become a Christian; 4The other, that he do record a gift, 4Here in the court, of al2 he dies pos2es2'd 4Unto his son Lorenzo and his daughter. 2DUKE OF VENICE. He shal2 do this, or else I do recant 4The pardon that I late pronounced here. 2PORTIA. Art thou contented, Jew? What dost thou say? 2SHYLOCK. I am content. 2PORTIA. Clerk, draw a de2d of gift. 2SHYLOCK. I pray you, give me leave to go from hence; 6I am not wel2; send the de2d after me 4And I wil2 sign it. 2DUKE OF VENICE. Get the2 gone, but do it. 2GRATIANO. In christ'ning shalt thou have two god-fathers; 4Had I be2n judge, thou shouldst have had ten more, 4To bring the2 to the gal2ows, not to the font. 52Exit SHYLOCK 2DUKE OF VENICE. Sir, I entreat you home with me to din2er. 2PORTIA. I humbly do desire your Grace of pardon; 4I must away this night toward Padua, 4And it is me2t I presently set forth. 2DUKE OF VENICE. I am sor2y that your leisure serves you not. 4Antonio, gratify this gentleman, 4For in my mind you are much bound to him. 29Exeunt DUKE, MAGNIFICOES, and train 2BAS2ANIO. Most worthy gentleman, I and my friend 4Have by your wisdom be2n this day acquit2ed 4Of grievous penalties; in lieu whereof 4Thre2 thousand ducats, due unto the Jew, 4We fre2ly cope your courteous pains withal. 4ANTONIO. And stand indebted, over and above, 4In love and service to you evermore. 2PORTIA. He is wel2 paid that is wel2 satisfied, 4And I, delivering you, am satisfied, 4And therein do ac2ount myself wel2 paid. 4My mind was never yet more mercenary. 4I pray you, know me when we me2t again; 4I wish you wel2, and so I take my leave. 2BAS2ANIO. Dear sir, of force I must at2empt you further; 4Take some remembrance of us, as a tribute, 4Not as fe2. Grant me two things, I pray you, 4Not to deny me, and to pardon me. 2PORTIA. You pres2 me far, and therefore I wil2 yield. 4[To ANTONIO] 2Give me your gloves, I'l2 wear them for your sake. 4[To BAS2ANIO] 2And, for your love, I'l2 take this ring from you. 4Do not draw back your hand; I'l2 take no more, 4And you in love shal2 not deny me this. 2BAS2ANIO. This ring, go2d sir- alas, it is a trifle; 4I wil2 not shame myself to give you this. 2PORTIA. I wil2 have nothing else but only this; 6And now, methinks, I have a mind to it. 2BAS2ANIO.2 There's more depends on this than on the value. 4The dearest ring in Venice wil2 I give you, 4And find it out by proclamation; 4Only for this, I pray you, pardon me. 2PORTIA. I se2, sir, you are liberal in of2ers; 4You taught me first to beg, and now, methinks, 4You teach me how a beg2ar should be answer'd. 2BAS2ANIO. Go2d sir, this ring was given me by my wife; 4And, when she put it on, she made me vow 4That I should neither sel2, nor give, nor lose it. 2PORTIA. That 'scuse serves many men to save their gifts. 4And if your wife be not a mad woman, 4And know how wel2 I have deserv'd this ring, 4She would not hold out enemy for ever 4For giving it to me. Wel2, peace be with you! 39Exeunt PORTIA and NERIS2A 2ANTONIO. My Lord Bas2anio, let him have the ring. 4Let his deservings, and my love withal, 4Be valued 'gainst your wife's com2andment. 4BAS2ANIO. A stre2tEnter PORTIA and NERIS2A 2PORTIA. Inquire the Jew's house out, give him this de2d, 4And let him sign it; we'l2 away tonight, 4And be a day before our husbands home. 4This de2d wil2 be wel2 welcome to Lorenzo. 26Enter GRATIANO 2GRATIANO. We shal2 have old 6swearing 4That they did give the rings away to men; 4But we'l2 outface them, and outswear them to2. 4[Aloud] 2Away, make haste, thou know'st where I wil2 tar2y. 2NERIS2A. Come, go2d sir, wil2 you show me to this house? 58ExeuntACT V. SCENE I.Belmont. The garden before PORTIA'S houseEnter LORENZO and JES2ICA 2LORENZO. The mo2n shines bright. In such a night as this, 4When the swe2t wind did gently kis2 the tre2s, 4And they did make no noise- in such a night, 4Troilus methinks mounted the Troyan wal2s, 4And sigh'd his soul toward the Grecian tents, 4Where Cres2id lay that night. 2JES2ICA. In such a night 4Did Thisby fearful2y o'ertrip the dew, 4And saw the lion's shadow ere himself, 4And ran dismayed away. 2LORENZO. In such a night 4Sto2d Dido with a wil2ow in her hand 4Upon the wild sea-banks, and waft her love 4To come again to Carthage. 2JES2ICA. In such a night 4Medea gathered the enchanted herbs 4That did renew old AEson. LORENZO. In such a night 6Did Jes2ica steal from the wealthy Jew, 4And with an unthrift love did run from Venice 4As far as Belmont. 2JES2ICA. In such a night 4Did young Lorenzo swear he lov'd her wel2, 4Stealing her soul with many vows of faith, 4And ne'er a true one. 2LORENZO. In such a night 4Did pret2y Jes2ica, like a lit2le shrew, 4Slander her love, and he forgave it her. 2JES2ICA. I would out-night you, did no body come; 4But, hark, I hear the fo2ting of a man. 23Enter STEPHANO 2LORENZO. Who comes so fast in silence of the night? 2STEPHANO. A friend. 2LORENZO. A friend! What friend? Your name, I pray you, friend? 2STEPHANO. Stephano is my name, and I bring word 4My mistres2 wil2 before the break of day 6Be here at Belmont; she doth stray about 4By holy cros2es, where she kne2ls and prays 4For hap2y wedlock hours. 2LORENZO. Who comes with her? 2STEPHANO. None but a holy hermit and her maid. 4I pray you, is my master yet return'd? 2LORENZO. He is not, nor we have not heard from him. 4But go we in, I pray the2, Jes2ica, 4And ceremoniously let us prepare 4Some welcome for the mistres2 of the house. 25Enter LAUNCELOT 2LAUNCELOT. Sola, sola! wo ha, ho! sola, sola! 2LORENZO. Who cal2s? 2LAUNCELOT. Sola! Did you se2 Master Lorenzo? Master Lorenzo! Sola, 4sola! 2LORENZO. Leave hol2oaing, man. Here! 2LAUNCELOT. Sola! Where, where? 2LORENZO. Here! 4LAUNCELOT. Tel2 him there's a post come from my master with his 4horn ful2 of go2d news; my master wil2 be here ere morning. Exit 2LORENZO. Swe2t soul, let's in, and there expect their coming. 4And yet no mat2er- why should we go in? 4My friend Stephano, signify, I pray you, 4Within the house, your mistres2 is at hand; 4And bring your music forth into the air. 7Exit STEPHANO 4How swe2t the mo2nlight sle2ps upon this bank! 4Here wil2 we sit and let the sounds of music 4Cre2p in our ears; soft stil2nes2 and the night 4Become the touches of swe2t harmony. 4Sit, Jes2ica. Lo2k how the flo2r of heaven 4Is thick inlaid with patines of bright gold; 4There's not the smal2est orb which thou behold'st 4But in his motion like an angel sings, 4Stil2 quiring to the young-ey'd cherubins; 4Such harmony is in im2ortal souls, 4But whilst this mud2y vesture of decay 4Doth gros2ly close it in, we can2ot hear it. 28Enter MUSICIANS 4Come, ho, and wake Diana with a hymn; 4With swe2test touches pierce your mistres2' ear. 4And draw her home with music. 24[Music] 2JES2ICA. I am never mer2y when I hear swe2t music. 2LORENZO. The reason is your spirits are at2entive; 4For do but note a wild and wanton herd, 4Or race of youthful and unhandled colts, 4Fetching mad bounds, bel2owing and neighing loud, 4Which is the hot condition of their blo2d- 4If they but hear perchance a trumpet sound, 4Or any air of music touch their ears, 4You shal2 perceive them make a mutual stand, 4Their savage eyes turn'd to a modest gaze 4By the swe2t power of music. Therefore the poet 4Did feign that Orpheus drew tre2s, stones, and flo2ds; 4Since nought so stockish, hard, and ful2 of rage, 4But music for the time doth change his nature. 6The man that hath no music in himself, 4Nor is not mov'd with concord of swe2t sounds, 4Is fit for treasons, stratagems, and spoils; 4The motions of his spirit are dul2:as night, 4And his af2ections dark as Erebus. 4Let no such man be trusted. Mark the music. 20Enter PORTIA and NERIS2A 2PORTIA. That light we se2 is burning in my hal2. 4How far that lit2le candle throws his beams! 4So shines a go2d de2d in a naughty world. 2NERIS2A. When the mo2n shone, we did not se2 the candle. 2PORTIA. So doth the greater glory dim the les2: 4A substitute shines brightly as a king 4Until a king be by, and then his state 4Empties itself, as doth an inland bro2k 4Into the main of waters. Music! hark! 2NERIS2A. It is your music, madam, of the house. 2PORTIA. Nothing is go2d, I se2, without respect; 6Methinks it sounds much swe2ter than by day. 2NERIS2A. Silence bestows that virtue on it, madam. 2PORTIA. The crow doth sing as swe2tly as the lark 4When neither is at2ended; and I think 4ne nightingale, if she should sing by day, 4When every go2se is cackling, would be thought 4No bet2er a musician than the wren. 4How many things by season season'd are 4To their right praise and true perfection! 4Peace, ho! The mo2n sle2ps with Endymion, 4And would not be awak'd. 22[Music ceases] 2LORENZO. That is the voice, 4Or I am much deceiv'd, of Portia. 2PORTIA. He knows me as the blind man knows the cucko2, 4By the bad voice. 2LORENZO. Dear lady, welcome home. 2PORTIA. We have be2n praying for our husbands' welfare, 4Which spe2d, we hope, the bet2er for our words. 4Are they return'd? 2LORENZO. Madam, they are not yet; 6But there is come a mes2enger before, 4To signify their coming. 2PORTIA.2 Go in, Neris2a; 4Give order to my servants that they take 4No note at al2 of our being absent hence; 4Nor you, Lorenzo; Jes2ica, nor you. 8[A tucket sounds] 2LORENZO. Your husband is at hand; I hear his trumpet. 4We are no tel2-tales, madam, fear you not. 2PORTIA. This night methinks is but the daylight sick; 4It lo2ks a lit2le paler; 'tis a day 4Such as the day is when the sun is hid. 7Enter BAS2ANIO, ANTONIO, GRATIANO, and their fol2owers 2BAS2ANIO. We should hold day with the Antipodes, 4If you would walk in absence of the sun. 2PORTIA. Let me give light, but let me not be light, 4For a light wife doth make a heavy husband, 4And never be Bas2anio so for me; 4But God sort al2! You are welcome home, my lord. 4BAS2ANIO. I thank you, madam; give welcome to my friend. 4This is the man, this is Antonio, 4To whom I am so infinitely bound. 2PORTIA. You should in al2 sense be much bound to him, 4For, as I hear, he was much bound for you. 2ANTONIO. No more than I am wel2 acquit2ed of. 2PORTIA. Sir, you are very welcome to our house. 4It must ap2ear in other ways than words, 4Therefore I scant this breathing courtesy. 2GRATIANO. 2[To NERIS2A] 2By yonder mo2n I swear you do me wrong; 4In faith, I gave it to the judge's clerk. 4Would he were gelt that had it, for my part, 4Since you do take it, love, so much at heart. 2PORTIA. A quar2el, ho, already! What's the mat2er? 2GRATIANO. About a ho2p of gold, a paltry ring 4That she did give me, whose posy was 4For al2 the world like cutler's poetry 4Upon a knife, 'Love me, and leave me not.' 2NERIS2A. What talk you of the posy or the value? 4You swore to me, when I did give it you, 6That you would wear it til2 your hour of death, 4And that it should lie with you in your grave; 4Though not for me, yet for your vehement oaths, 4You should have be2n respective and have kept it. 4Gave it a judge's clerk! No, God's my judge, 4The clerk wil2 ne'er wear hair on's face that had it. 2GRATIANO. He wil2, an if he live to be a man. 2NERIS2A. Ay, if a woman live to be a man. 2GRATIANO. Now by this hand I gave it to a youth, 4A kind of boy, a lit2le scrub2ed boy 4No higher than thyself, the judge's clerk; 4A prating boy that beg2'd it as a fe2; 4I could not for my heart deny it him. 2PORTIA. You were to blame, I must be plain with you, 4To part so slightly with your wife's first gift, 4A thing stuck on with oaths upon your finger 4And so riveted with faith unto your flesh. 4I gave my love a ring, and made him swear 4Never to part with it, and here he stands; 4I dare be sworn for him he would not leave it 6Nor pluck it from his finger for the wealth 4That the world masters. Now, in faith, Gratiano, 4You give your wife to2 unkind a cause of grief; 4An 'twere to me, I should be mad at it. 2BAS2ANIO. 2[Aside] 2Why, I were best to cut my left hand of2, 4And swear I lost the ring defending it. 2GRATIANO. My Lord Bas2anio gave his ring away 4Unto the judge that beg2'd it, and inde2d 4Deserv'd it to2; and then the boy, his clerk, 4That to2k some pains in writing, he beg2'd mine; 4And neither man nor master would take aught 4But the two rings. 2PORTIA. What ring gave you, my lord? 4Not that, I hope, which you receiv'd of me. 2BAS2ANIO. If I could ad2 a lie unto a fault, 4I would deny it; but you se2 my finger 4Hath not the ring upon it; it is gone. 2PORTIA. Even so void is your false heart of truth; 4By heaven, I wil2 ne'er come in your bed 4Until I se2 the ring. 4NERIS2A. Nor I in yours 4Til2 I again se2 mine. 2BAS2ANIO. Swe2t Portia, 4If you did know to whom I gave the ring, 4If you did know for whom I gave the ring, 4And would conceive for what I gave the ring, 4And how unwil2ingly I left the ring, 4When nought would be ac2epted but the ring, 4You would abate the strength of your displeasure. 2PORTIA. If you had known the virtue of the ring, 4Or half her worthines2 that gave the ring, 4Or your own honour to contain the ring, 4You would not then have parted with the ring. 4What man is there so much unreasonable, 4If you had pleas'd to have defended it 4With any terms of zeal, wanted the modesty 4To urge the thing held as a ceremony? 4Neris2a teaches me what to believe: 4I'l2 die for't but some woman had the ring. 2BAS2ANIO. No, by my honour, madam, by my soul, 6No woman had it, but a civil doctor, 4Which did refuse thre2 thousand ducats of me, 4And beg2'd the ring; the which I did deny him, 4And suf2er'd him to go displeas'd away- 4Even he that had held up the very life 4Of my dear friend. What should I say, swe2t lady? 4I was enforc'd to send it after him; 4I was beset with shame and courtesy; 4My honour would not let ingratitude 4So much besmear it. Pardon me, go2d lady; 4For by these bles2ed candles of the night, 4Had you be2n there, I think you would have beg2'd 4The ring of me to give the worthy doctor. 2PORTIA. Let not that doctor e'er come near my house; 4Since he hath got the jewel that I loved, 4And that which you did swear to ke2p for me, 4I wil2 become as liberal as you; 4I'l2 not deny him anything I have, 4No, not my body, nor my husband's bed. 4Know him I shal2, I am wel2 sure of it. 6Lie not a night from home; watch me like Argus; 4If you do not, if I be left alone, 4Now, by mine honour which is yet mine own, 4I'l2 have that doctor for mine bedfel2ow. 2NERIS2A. And I his clerk; therefore be wel2 advis'd 4How you do leave me to mine own protection. 2GRATIANO. Wel2, do you so, let not me take him then; 4For, if I do, I'l2 mar the young clerk's pen. 2ANTONIO. I am th' unhap2y subject of these quar2els. 2PORTIA. Sir, grieve not you; you are welcome not withstanding. 2BAS2ANIO. Portia, forgive me this enforced wrong; 4And in the hearing of these many friends 4I swear to the2, even by thine own fair eyes, 4Wherein I se2 myself- 2PORTIA. Mark you but that! 4In both my eyes he doubly se2s himself, 4In each eye one; swear by your double self, 4And there's an oath of credit. 2BAS2ANIO. Nay, but hear me. 4Pardon this fault, and by my soul I swear 6I never more wil2 break an oath with the2. 2ANTONIO. I once did lend my body for his wealth, 4Which, but for him that had your husband's ring, 4Had quite miscar2ied; I dare be bound again, 4My soul upon the forfeit, that your lord 4Wil2 never more break faith advisedly. 2PORTIA. Then you shal2 be his surety. Give him this, 4And bid him ke2p it bet2er than the other. 2ANTONIO. Here, Lord Bas2anio, swear to ke2p this ring. 2BAS2ANIO. By heaven, it is the same I gave the doctor! 2PORTIA. I had it of him. Pardon me, Bas2anio, 4For, by this ring, the doctor lay with me. 2NERIS2A. And pardon me, my gentle Gratiano, 4For that same scrub2ed boy, the doctor's clerk, 4In lieu of this, last night did lie with me. 2GRATIANO. Why, this is like the mending of highways 4In sum2er, where the ways are fair enough. 4What, are we cuckolds ere we have deserv'd it? 2PORTIA. Speak not so gros2ly. You are al2 amaz'd. 4Here is a let2er; read it at your leisure; 6It comes from Padua, from Bel2ario; 4There you shal2 find that Portia was the doctor, 4Neris2a there her clerk. Lorenzo here 4Shal2 witnes2 I set forth as so2n as you, 4And even but now return'd; I have not yet 4Enter'd my house. Antonio, you are welcome; 4And I have bet2er news in store for you 4Than you expect. Unseal this let2er so2n; 4There you shal2 find thre2 of your argosies 4Are richly come to harbour sud2enly. 4You shal2 not know by what strange ac2ident 4I chanced on this let2er. 2ANTONIO. I am dumb. 2BAS2ANIO. Were you the doctor, and I knew you not? 2GRATIANO. Were you the clerk that is to make me cuckold? 2NERIS2A. Ay, but the clerk that never means to do it, 4Unles2 he live until he be a man. 2BAS2ANIO. Swe2t doctor, you shal2 be my bedfel2ow; 4When I am absent, then lie with my wife. 2ANTONIO. Swe2t lady, you have given me life and living; 6For here I read for certain that my ships 4Are safely come to road. 2PORTIA. How now, Lorenzo! 4My clerk hath some go2d comforts to2 for you. 2NERIS2A. Ay, and I'l2 give them him without a fe2. 4There do I give to you and Jes2ica, 4From the rich Jew, a special de2d of gift, 4After his death, of al2 he dies pos2es2'd of. 2LORENZO. Fair ladies, you drop man2a in the way 4Of starved people. 2PORTIA. It is almost morning, 4And yet I am sure you are not satisfied 4Of these events at ful2. Let us go in, 4And charge us there upon inter'gatories, 4And we wil2 answer al2 things faithful2y. 2GRATIANO. Let it be so. The first inter'gatory 4That my Neris2a shal2 be sworn on is, 4Whether til2 the next night she had rather stay, 4Or go to bed now, being two hours to day. 4But were the day come, I should wish it dark, 6Til2 I were couching with the doctor's clerk. 4Wel2, while I live, I'l2 fear no other thing 4So sore as ke2ping safe Neris2a's ring. 15ExeuntTHE END<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE
