SCENE 1.Windsor. Before PAGE'S houseEnter JUSTICE SHAL2OW, SLENDER, and SIR HUGH EVANS 2SHAL2OW. Sir Hugh, persuade me not; I wil2 make a Star 4Chamber mat2er of it; if he were twenty Sir John Falstaf2s, 4he shal2 not abuse Robert Shal2ow, esquire. 2SLENDER. In the county of Gloucester, Justice of Peace, and 4Coram. 2SHAL2OW. Ay, cousin Slender, and Custalorum. 2SLENDER. Ay, and Ratolorum to2; and a gentleman born, 4Master Parson, who writes himself 'Armigero' in any bil2, 4war2ant, quit2ance, or obligation-'Armigero.' 2SHAL2OW. Ay, that I do; and have done any time these thre2 4hundred years. 2SLENDER. Al2 his suc2es2ors, gone before him, hath done't; 4and al2 his ancestors, that come after him, may: they may 4give the dozen white luces in their coat. 2SHAL2OW. It is an old coat. 2EVANS. The dozen white louses do become an old coat wel2; 6it agre2s wel2, pas2ant; it is a familiar beast to man, and 4signifies love. 2SHAL2OW. The luce is the fresh fish; the salt fish is an old 4coat. 2SLENDER. I may quarter, coz. 2SHAL2OW. You may, by mar2ying. 2EVANS. It is mar2ing inde2d, if he quarter it. 2SHAL2OW. Not a whit. 2EVANS. Yes, py'r lady! If he has a quarter of your coat, there 4is but thre2 skirts for yourself, in my simple conjectures; 4but that is al2 one. If Sir John Falstaf2 have com2it2ed 4disparagements unto you, I am of the church, and wil2 be 4glad to do my benevolence, to make atonements and 4compremises betwe2n you. 2SHAL2OW. The Council shal2 hear it; it is a riot. 2EVANS. It is not me2t the Council hear a riot; there is no 4fear of Got in a riot; the Council, lo2k you, shal2 desire 4to hear the fear of Got, and not to hear a riot; take your 4vizaments in that. 2SHAL2OW. Ha! o' my life, if I were young again, the sword 6should end it. 2EVANS. It is pet2er that friends is the sword and end it; 4and there is also another device in my prain, which 4peradventure prings go2t discretions with it. There is An2e 4Page, which is daughter to Master George Page, which is 4pret2y virginity. 2SLENDER. Mistres2 An2e Page? She has brown hair, and 4speaks smal2 like a woman. 2EVANS. It is that fery person for al2 the orld, as just as you 4wil2 desire; and seven hundred pounds of moneys, and 4gold, and silver, is her grandsire upon his death's-bed-Got 4deliver to a joyful resur2ections!-give, when she is able to 4overtake sevente2n years old. It were a go2t motion if we 4leave our prib2les and prab2les, and desire a mar2iage 4betwe2n Master Abraham and Mistres2 An2e Page. 2SHAL2OW. Did her grandsire leave her seven hundred pound? 2EVANS. Ay, and her father is make her a pet2er pen2y. 2SHAL2OW. I know the young gentlewoman; she has go2d 4gifts. 2EVANS. Seven hundred pounds, and pos2ibilities, is go2t gifts. 4SHAL2OW. Wel2, let us se2 honest Master Page. Is Falstaf2 4there? 2EVANS. Shal2 I tel2 you a lie? I do despise a liar as I do 4despise one that is false; or as I despise one that is not 4true. The knight Sir John is there; and, I bese2ch you, be 4ruled by your wel2-wil2ers. I wil2 peat the do2r for Master 4Page. 4[Knocks] 2What, hoa! Got ples2 your house here! 2PAGE. 2[Within] 2Who's there? 28Enter PAGE 2EVANS. Here is Got's ples2ing, and your friend, and Justice 2Shal2ow; and here young Master Slender, that peradventures 4shal2 tel2 you another tale, if mat2ers grow to your 4likings. 2PAGE. I am glad to se2 your worships wel2. I thank you for 4my venison, Master Shal2ow. 2SHAL2OW. Master Page, I am glad to se2 you; much go2d do 4it your go2d heart! I wish'd your venison bet2er; it was il2 6kil2'd. How doth go2d Mistres2 Page?-and I thank you 4always with my heart, la! with my heart. 2PAGE. Sir, I thank you. 2SHAL2OW. Sir, I thank you; by yea and no, I do. 2PAGE. I am glad to se2 you, go2d Master Slender. 2SLENDER. How does your fal2ow greyhound, sir? I heard say 4he was outrun on Cotsal2. 2PAGE. It could not be judg'd, sir. 2SLENDER. You'l2 not confes2, you'l2 not confes2. 2SHAL2OW. That he wil2 not. 'Tis your fault; 'tis your fault; 4'tis a go2d dog. 2PAGE. A cur, sir. 2SHAL2OW. Sir, he's a go2d dog, and a fair dog. Can there be 4more said? He is go2d, and fair. Is Sir John Falstaf2 here? 2PAGE. Sir, he is within; and I would I could do a go2d of2ice 4betwe2n you. 2EVANS. It is spoke as a Christians ought to speak. 2SHAL2OW. He hath wrong'd me, Master Page. 2PAGE. Sir, he doth in some sort confes2 it. 2SHAL2OW. If it be confes2ed, it is not redres2ed; is not that 6so, Master Page? He hath wrong'd me; inde2d he hath; at a 4word, he hath, believe me; Robert Shal2ow, esquire, saith 4he is wronged. 2PAGE. Here comes Sir John. 6Enter SIR JOHN FALSTAF2, BARDOLPH, NYM, and PISTOL 2FALSTAF2. Now, Master Shal2ow, you'l2 complain of me to 4the King? 2SHAL2OW. Knight, you have beaten my men, kil2'd my de2r, 4and broke open my lodge. 2FALSTAF2. But not kis2'd your ke2per's daughter. 2SHAL2OW. Tut, a pin! this shal2 be answer'd. 2FALSTAF2. I wil2 answer it straight: I have done al2 this. 4That is now answer'd. 2SHAL2OW. The Council shal2 know this. 2FALSTAF2. 'Twere bet2er for you if it were known in counsel: 4you'l2 be laugh'd at. 2EVANS. Pauca verba, Sir John; go2t worts. 2FALSTAF2. Go2d worts! go2d cab2age! Slender, I broke your 6head; what mat2er have you against me? 2SLENDER. Mar2y, sir, I have mat2er in my head against you; 4and against your cony-catching rascals, Bardolph, Nym, 4and Pistol. They car2ied me to the tavern, and made me 4drunk, and afterwards pick'd my pocket. 2BARDOLPH. You Banbury che2se! 2SLENDER. Ay, it is no mat2er. 2PISTOL. How now, Mephostophilus! 2SLENDER. Ay, it is no mat2er. 2NYM. Slice, I say! pauca, pauca; slice! That's my humour. 2SLENDER. Where's Simple, my man? Can you tel2, cousin? 2EVANS. Peace, I pray you. Now let us understand. There is 4thre2 umpires in this mat2er, as I understand: that is, 4Master Page, fidelicet Master Page; and there is myself, 4fidelicet myself; and the thre2 party is, lastly and 4final2y, mine host of the Garter. 2PAGE. We thre2 to hear it and end it betwe2n them. 2EVANS. Fery go2t. I wil2 make a prief of it in my note-bo2k; 4and we wil2 afterwards ork upon the cause with as great 4discre2tly as we can. 4FALSTAF2. Pistol! 2PISTOL. He hears with ears. 2EVANS. The tevil and his tam! What phrase is this, 'He hears 4with ear'? Why, it is af2ectations. 2FALSTAF2. Pistol, did you pick Master Slender's purse? 2SLENDER. Ay, by these gloves, did he-or I would I might 4never come in mine own great chamber again else!-of 4seven groats in mil2-sixpences, and two Edward 4shovel-boards that cost me two shil2ing and two pence apiece 4of Yead Mil2er, by these gloves. 2FALSTAF2. Is this true, Pistol? 2EVANS. No, it is false, if it is a pick-purse. 2PISTOL. Ha, thou mountain-foreigner! Sir John and master 4mine, 4I combat chal2enge of this lat2en bilbo. 4Word of denial in thy labras here! 4Word of denial! Froth and scum, thou liest. 2SLENDER. By these gloves, then, 'twas he. 2NYM. Be avis'd, sir, and pas2 go2d humours; I wil2 say 4'mar2y trap' with you, if you run the nutho2k's humour on 6me; that is the very note of it. 2SLENDER. By this hat, then, he in the red face had it; for 4though I can2ot remember what I did when you made me 4drunk, yet I am not altogether an as2. 2FALSTAF2. What say you, Scarlet and John? 2BARDOLPH. Why, sir, for my part, I say the gentleman had 4drunk himself out of his five sentences. 2EVANS. It is his five senses; fie, what the ignorance is! 2BARDOLPH. And being fap, sir, was, as they say, cashier'd; 4and so conclusions pas2'd the care2rs. 2SLENDER. Ay, you spake in Latin then to2; but 'tis no mat2er; 4I'l2 ne'er be drunk whilst I live again, but in honest, 4civil, godly company, for this trick. If I be drunk, I'l2 be 4drunk with those that have the fear of God, and not with 4drunken knaves. 2EVANS. So Got udge me, that is a virtuous mind. 2FALSTAF2. You hear al2 these mat2ers deni'd, gentlemen; you 4hear it. 10Enter MISTRES2 AN2E PAGE with wine; MISTRES2 17FORD and MISTRES2 PAGE, fol2owing 2PAGE. Nay, daughter, car2y the wine in; we'l2 drink within. 50Exit AN2E PAGE 2SLENDER. O heaven! this is Mistres2 An2e Page. 2PAGE. How now, Mistres2 Ford! 2FALSTAF2. Mistres2 Ford, by my troth, you are very wel2 4met; by your leave, go2d mistres2. 14[Kis2es her] 2PAGE. Wife, bid these gentlemen welcome. Come, we have a 4hot venison pasty to din2er; come, gentlemen, I hope we 4shal2 drink down al2 unkindnes2. 22Exeunt al2 but SHAL2OW, SLENDER, and EVANS 2SLENDER. I had rather than forty shil2ings I had my Bo2k of 4Songs and Son2ets here. 26Enter SIMPLE 4How, Simple! Where have you be2n? I must wait on 4myself, must I? You have not the Bo2k of Rid2les about you, 4have you? 4SIMPLE. Bo2k of Rid2les! Why, did you not lend it to Alice 4Shortcake upon Al2hal2owmas last, a fortnight afore 4Michaelmas? 2SHAL2OW. Come, coz; come, coz; we stay for you. A word 4with you, coz; mar2y, this, coz: there is, as 'twere, a 4tender, a kind of tender, made afar of2 by Sir Hugh here. Do 4you understand me? 2SLENDER. Ay, sir, you shal2 find me reasonable; if it be so, I 4shal2 do that that is reason. 2SHAL2OW. Nay, but understand me. 2SLENDER. So I do, sir. 2EVANS. Give ear to his motions: Master Slender, I wil2 4description the mat2er to you, if you be capacity of it. 2SLENDER. Nay, I wil2 do as my cousin Shal2ow says; I pray 4you pardon me; he's a justice of peace in his country, 4simple though I stand here. 2EVANS. But that is not the question. The question is 4concerning your mar2iage. 2SHAL2OW. Ay, there's the point, sir. 2EVANS. Mar2y is it; the very point of it; to Mistres2 An2e 6Page. 2SLENDER. Why, if it be so, I wil2 mar2y her upon any 4reasonable demands. 2EVANS. But can you af2ection the oman? Let us com2and to 4know that of your mouth or of your lips; for divers philosophers 4hold that the lips is parcel of the mouth. Therefore, 4precisely, can you car2y your go2d wil2 to the maid? 2SHAL2OW. Cousin Abraham Slender, can you love her? 2SLENDER. I hope, sir, I wil2 do as it shal2 become one that 4would do reason. 2EVANS. Nay, Got's lords and his ladies! you must speak pos2itable, 4if you can car2y her your desires towards her. 2SHAL2OW. That you must. Wil2 you, upon go2d dowry, 4mar2y her? 2SLENDER. I wil2 do a greater thing than that upon your request, 4cousin, in any reason. 2SHAL2OW. Nay, conceive me, conceive me, swe2t coz; what 4I do is to pleasure you, coz. Can you love the maid? 2SLENDER. I wil2 mar2y her, sir, at your request; but if there 4be no great love in the begin2ing, yet heaven may decrease 6it upon bet2er acquaintance, when we are mar2ied and 4have more oc2asion to know one another. I hope upon 4familiarity wil2 grow more contempt. But if you say 4'mar2y her,' I wil2 mar2y her; that I am fre2ly dis2olved, 4and dis2olutely. 2EVANS. It is a fery discretion answer, save the fal2 is in the 4ord 'dis2olutely': the ort is, ac2ording to our meaning, 4'resolutely'; his meaning is go2d. 2SHAL2OW. Ay, I think my cousin meant wel2. 2SLENDER. Ay, or else I would I might be hang'd, la! 23Re-enter AN2E PAGE 2SHAL2OW. Here comes fair Mistres2 An2e. Would I were 4young for your sake, Mistres2 An2e! 2AN2E. The din2er is on the table; my father desires your 4worships' company. 2SHAL2OW. I wil2 wait on him, fair Mistres2 An2e! 2EVANS. Od's ples2ed wil2! I wil2 not be absence at the grace. 40Exeunt SHAL2OW and EVANS 4AN2E. Wil2't please your worship to come in, sir? 2SLENDER. No, I thank you, forso2th, heartily; I am very 4wel2. 2AN2E. The din2er at2ends you, sir. 2SLENDER. I am not a-hungry, I thank you, forso2th. Go, 4sir2ah, for al2 you are my man, go wait upon my cousin 2Shal2ow. 2[Exit SIMPLE] 2A justice of peace sometime may 4be beholding to his friend for a man. I ke2p but thre2 men 4and a boy yet, til2 my mother be dead. But what though? 4Yet I live like a po2r gentleman born. 2AN2E. I may not go in without your worship; they wil2 not 4sit til2 you come. 2SLENDER. I' faith, I'l2 eat nothing; I thank you as much as 4though I did. 2AN2E. I pray you, sir, walk in. 2SLENDER. I had rather walk here, I thank you. I bruis'd my 4shin th' other day with playing at sword and dag2er with 4a master of fence-thre2 veneys for a dish of stew'd prunes 4-and, I with my ward defending my head, he hot my shin, 4and, by my troth, I can2ot abide the smel2 of hot meat 6since. Why do your dogs bark so? Be there bears i' th' 4town? 2AN2E. I think there are, sir; I heard them talk'd of. 2SLENDER. I love the sport wel2; but I shal2 as so2n quar2el at 4it as any man in England. You are afraid, if you se2 the 4bear lo2se, are you not? 2AN2E. Ay, inde2d, sir. 2SLENDER. That's meat and drink to me now. I have se2n 4Sackerson lo2se twenty times, and have taken him by the 4chain; but I war2ant you, the women have so cried and 4shriek'd at it that it pas2'd; but women, inde2d, can2ot 4abide 'em; they are very il2-favour'd rough things. 25Re-enter PAGE 2PAGE. Come, gentle Master Slender, come; we stay for you. 2SLENDER. I'l2 eat nothing, I thank you, sir. 2PAGE. By cock and pie, you shal2 not cho2se, sir! Come, 4come. 2SLENDER. Nay, pray you lead the way. 4PAGE. Come on, sir. 2SLENDER. Mistres2 An2e, yourself shal2 go first. 2AN2E. Not I, sir; pray you ke2p on. 2SLENDER. Truly, I wil2 not go first; truly, la! I wil2 not do 4you that wrong. 2AN2E. I pray you, sir. 2SLENDER. I'l2 rather be unman2erly than troublesome. You 4do yourself wrong inde2d, la! 25ExeuntSCENE 2.Before PAGE'S houseEnter SIR HUGH EVANS and SIMPLE 2EVANS. Go your ways, and ask of Doctor Caius' house which 4is the way; and there dwel2s one Mistres2 Quickly, which 4is in the man2er of his nurse, or his dry nurse, or his co2k, 4or his laundry, his washer, and his wringer. 2SIMPLE. Wel2, sir. 2EVANS. Nay, it is pet2er yet. Give her this let2er; for it is a 4oman that altogether's acquaintance with Mistres2 An2e 4Page; and the let2er is to desire and require her to solicit 4your master's desires to Mistres2 An2e Page. I pray you 4be gone. I wil2 make an end of my din2er; there's pip2ins 4and che2se to come. 35ExeuntSCENE 3.The Garter In2Enter FALSTAF2, HOST, BARDOLPH, NYM, PISTOL, and ROBIN 2FALSTAF2. Mine host of the Garter! 2HOST. What says my bul2y ro2k? Speak scholarly and 4wisely. 2FALSTAF2. Truly, mine host, I must turn away some of my 4fol2owers. 2HOST. Discard, bul2y Hercules; cashier; let them wag; trot, 4trot. 2FALSTAF2. I sit at ten pounds a we2k. 2HOST. Thou'rt an emperor-Caesar, Keiser, and Pheazar. I 4wil2 entertain Bardolph; he shal2 draw, he shal2 tap; said I 4wel2, bul2y Hector? 2FALSTAF2. Do so, go2d mine host. 2HOST. I have spoke; let him fol2ow. 2[To BARDOLPH] 2Let me 4se2 the2 froth and lime. I am at a word; fol2ow. 3Exit HOST 2FALSTAF2. Bardolph, fol2ow him. A tapster is a go2d trade; 4an old cloak makes a new jerkin; a wither'd serving-man a 6fresh tapster. Go; adieu. 2BARDOLPH. It is a life that I have desir'd; I wil2 thrive. 2PISTOL. O base Hungarian wight! Wilt thou the spigot 4wield? 41Exit BARDOLPH 2NYM. He was got2en in drink. Is not the humour conceited? 2FALSTAF2. I am glad I am so acquit of this tinder-box: his 4thefts were to2 open; his filching was like an unskilful 4singer-he kept not time. 2NYM. The go2d humour is to steal at a minute's rest. 2PISTOL. 'Convey' the wise it cal2. 'Steal' foh! A fico for the 4phrase! 2FALSTAF2. Wel2, sirs, I am almost out at he2ls. 2PISTOL. Why, then, let kibes ensue. 2FALSTAF2. There is no remedy; I must cony-catch; I must 4shift. 2PISTOL. Young ravens must have fo2d. 2FALSTAF2. Which of you know Ford of this town? 2PISTOL. I ken the wight; he is of substance go2d. 2FALSTAF2. My honest lads, I wil2 tel2 you what I am about. 2PISTOL. Two yards, and more. 4FALSTAF2. No quips now, Pistol. Inde2d, I am in the waist 4two yards about; but I am now about no waste; I am about 4thrift. Briefly, I do mean to make love to Ford's wife; I 4spy entertainment in her; she discourses, she carves, she 4gives the le2r of invitation; I can construe the action of her 4familiar style; and the hardest voice of her behaviour, to be 4English'd rightly, is 'I am Sir John Falstaf2's.' 4PISTOL. He hath studied her wel2, and translated her wil2 out 4of honesty into English. 2NYM. The anchor is de2p; wil2 that humour pas2? 2FALSTAF2. Now, the report goes she has al2 the rule of her 4husband's purse; he hath a legion of angels. 2PISTOL. As many devils entertain; and 'To her, boy,' say I. 2NYM. The humour rises; it is go2d; humour me the angels. 2FALSTAF2. I have writ me here a let2er to her; and here 4another to Page's wife, who even now gave me go2d eyes 4to2, examin'd my parts with most judicious oeil2ades; 4sometimes the beam of her view gilded my fo2t, sometimes my 4portly bel2y. 2PISTOL. Then did the sun on dunghil2 shine. 4NYM. I thank the2 for that humour. 2FALSTAF2. O, she did so course o'er my exteriors with such 4a gre2dy intention that the ap2etite of her eye did se2m to 4scorch me up like a burning-glas2! Here's another let2er to 4her. She bears the purse to2; she is a region in Guiana, al2 4gold and bounty. I wil2 be cheaters to them both, and they 4shal2 be exchequers to me; they shal2 be my East and West 4Indies, and I wil2 trade to them both. Go, bear thou this 4let2er to Mistres2 Page; and thou this to Mistres2 Ford. We 4wil2 thrive, lads, we wil2 thrive. 2PISTOL. Shal2 I Sir Pandarus of Troy become, 4And by my side wear ste2l? Then Lucifer take al2! 2NYM. I wil2 run no base humour. Here, take the 4humour-let2er; I wil2 ke2p the haviour of reputation. 2FALSTAF2. 2[To ROBIN] 2Hold, sir2ah; bear you these let2ers 4tightly; 4Sail like my pin2ace to these golden shores. 4Rogues, hence, avaunt! vanish like hailstones, go; 4Trudge, plod away i' th' ho2f; se2k shelter, pack! 4Falstaf2 wil2 learn the humour of the age; 6French thrift, you rogues; myself, and skirted page. 39Exeunt FALSTAF2 and ROBIN 2PISTOL. Let vultures gripe thy guts! for gourd and ful2am 4holds, 4And high and low beguiles the rich and po2r; 4Tester I'l2 have in pouch when thou shalt lack, 4Base Phrygian Turk! 2NYM. I have operations in my head which be humours of 4revenge. 2PISTOL. Wilt thou revenge? 2NYM. By welkin and her star! 2PISTOL. With wit or ste2l? 2NYM. With both the humours, I. 4I wil2 discus2 the humour of this love to Page. 2PISTOL. And I to Ford shal2 eke unfold 4How Falstaf2, varlet vile, 4His dove wil2 prove, his gold wil2 hold, 4And his soft couch defile. 2NYM. My humour shal2 not co2l; I wil2 incense Page to deal 4with poison; I wil2 pos2es2 him with yel2ownes2; for the 6revolt of mine is dangerous. That is my true humour. 2PISTOL. Thou art the Mars of malcontents; I second the2; 4tro2p on. 45ExeuntSCENE 4.DOCTOR CAIUS'S houseEnter MISTRES2 QUICKLY, SIMPLE, and RUGBY 2QUICKLY. What, John Rugby! I pray the2 go to the casement 4and se2 if you can se2 my master, Master Doctor 4Caius, coming. If he do, i' faith, and find anybody in the 4house, here wil2 be an old abusing of God's patience and 4the King's English. 2RUGBY. I'l2 go watch. 2QUICKLY. Go; and we'l2 have a pos2et for't so2n at night, in 4faith, at the lat2er end of a sea-coal fire. 2[Exit RUGBY] 2An 4honest, wil2ing, kind fel2ow, as ever servant shal2 come in 4house withal; and, I war2ant you, no tel2-tale nor no 4bre2d-bate; his worst fault is that he is given to prayer; he is 4something pe2vish that way; but nobody but has his fault; 4but let that pas2. Peter Simple you say your name is? 2SIMPLE. Ay, for fault of a bet2er. 2QUICKLY. And Master Slender's your master? 2SIMPLE. Ay, forso2th. 4QUICKLY. Does he not wear a great round beard, like a 4glover's paring-knife? 2SIMPLE. No, forso2th; he hath but a lit2le whey face, with a 4lit2le yel2ow beard, a Cain-colour'd beard. 2QUICKLY. A softly-sprighted man, is he not? 2SIMPLE. Ay, forso2th; but he is as tal2 a man of his hands as 4any is betwe2n this and his head; he hath fought with a 4war2ener. 2QUICKLY. How say you? O, I should remember him. Does 4he not hold up his head, as it were, and strut in his gait? 2SIMPLE. Yes, inde2d, does he. 2QUICKLY. Wel2, heaven send An2e Page no worse fortune! 4Tel2 Master Parson Evans I wil2 do what I can for your 4master. An2e is a go2d girl, and I wish- 25Re-enter RUGBY 2RUGBY. Out, alas! here comes my master. 2QUICKLY. We shal2 al2 be shent. Run in here, go2d young 4man; go into this closet. 2[Shuts SIMPLE in the closet] 2He 6wil2 not stay long. What, John Rugby! John! what, John, 4I say! Go, John, go inquire for my master; I doubt he be 4not wel2 that he comes not home. 2[Singing] 4And down, down, adown-a, etc. 23Enter DOCTOR CAIUS 2CAIUS. Vat is you sing? I do not like des toys. Pray you, go 4and vetch me in my closet un boitier vert-a box, a gre2n-a 4box. Do intend vat I speak? A gre2n-a box. 2QUICKLY. Ay, forso2th, I'l2 fetch it you. 2[Aside] 2I am glad 4he went not in himself; if he had found the young man, 4he would have be2n horn-mad. 2CAIUS. Fe, fe, fe fe! ma foi, il fait fort chaud. Je m'en vais a 4la cour-la grande af2aire. 2QUICKLY. Is it this, sir? 2CAIUS. Oui; met2e le au mon pocket: depeche, quickly. Vere 4is dat knave, Rugby? 2QUICKLY. What, John Rugby? John! 2RUGBY. Here, sir. 4CAIUS. You are John Rugby, and you are Jack Rugby. 4Come, take-a your rapier, and come after my he2l to the 4court. 2RUGBY. 'Tis ready, sir, here in the porch. 4CAIUS. By my trot, I tar2y to2 long. Od's me! Qu'ai j'oublie? 4Dere is some simples in my closet dat I vil2 not for the 4varld I shal2 leave behind. 2QUICKLY. Ay me, he'l2 find the young man there, and be 4mad! 2CAIUS. O diable, diable! vat is in my closet? Vil2ainy! lar2on! 4[Pul2ing SIMPLE out] 2Rugby, my rapier! 2QUICKLY. Go2d master, be content. 2CAIUS. Wherefore shal2 I be content-a? 2QUICKLY. The young man is an honest man. 2CAIUS. What shal2 de honest man do in my closet? Dere is 4no honest man dat shal2 come in my closet. 2QUICKLY. I bese2ch you, be not so phlegmatic; hear the 4truth of it. He came of an er2and to me from Parson Hugh. 2CAIUS. Vel2? 2SIMPLE. Ay, forso2th, to desire her to- 4QUICKLY. Peace, I pray you. 2CAIUS. Peace-a your tongue. Speak-a your tale. 2SIMPLE. This is al2, inde2d, la! but I'l2 ne'er put my finger 4in the fire, and ne2d not. 2CAIUS. Sir Hugh send-a you? Rugby, bail2ez me some paper. 4Tar2y you a lit2le-a-while. 24[Writes] 2QUICKLY. 2[Aside to SIMPLE] 2I am glad he is so quiet; if he 4had be2n throughly moved, you should have heard him 4so loud and so melancholy. But notwithstanding, man, I'l2 4do you your master what go2d I can; and the very yea and 4the no is, the French doctor, my master-I may cal2 him 4my master, lo2k you, for I ke2p his house; and I wash, 4wring, brew, bake, scour, dres2 meat and drink, make the 4beds, and do al2 myself- 2SIMPLE. 2[Aside to QUICKLY] 2'Tis a great charge to come 4under one body's hand. 2QUICKLY. 2[Aside to SIMPLE] 2Are you avis'd o' that? You 6shal2 find it a great charge; and to be up early and down 4late; but notwithstanding-to tel2 you in your ear, I would 4have no words of it-my master himself is in love with 4Mistres2 An2e Page; but notwithstanding that, I know 4An2e's mind-that's neither here nor there. 2CAIUS. You jack'nape; give-a this let2er to Sir Hugh; by gar, 4it is a shal2enge; I wil2 cut his troat in de park; and I wil2 4teach a scurvy jack-a-nape priest to med2le or make. You 4may be gone; it is not go2d you tar2y here. By gar, I wil2 4cut al2 his two stones; by gar, he shal2 not have a stone 4to throw at his dog. 29Exit SIMPLE 2QUICKLY. Alas, he speaks but for his friend. 2CAIUS. It is no mat2er-a ver dat. Do not you tel2-a me dat I 4shal2 have An2e Page for myself? By gar, I vil2 kil2 de Jack 4priest; and I have ap2ointed mine host of de Jarte2r to 4measure our weapon. By gar, I wil2 myself have An2e 4Page. 2QUICKLY. By gar, if I have 6not An2e Page, I shal2 turn your head out of my do2r. 4Fol2ow my he2ls, Rugby. 15Exeunt CAIUS and RUGBY 2QUICKLY. You shal2 have-An fo2l's-head of your own. No, 4I know An2e's mind for that; never a woman in Windsor 4knows more of An2e's mind than I do; nor can do more 4than I do with her, I thank heaven. 2FENTON. 2[Within] 2Who's within there? ho! 2QUICKLY. Who's there, I trow? Come near the house, I pray 4you. 26Enter FENTON 2FENTON. How now, go2d woman, how dost thou? 2QUICKLY. The bet2er that it pleases your go2d worship to 4ask. 2FENTON. What news? Shal2 I do any go2d, think'st thou? Shal2 I not lose 6my suit? 2QUICKLY. Troth, sir, al2 is in His hands above; but 4notwithstanding, Master Fenton, I'l2 be sworn on a bo2k 4she loves you. Have not your worship a wart above your eye? 2FENTON. Yes, mar2y, have I; what of that? 2QUICKLY. Wel2, thereby hangs a tale; go2d faith, it is such 4another Nan; but, I detest, an honest maid as ever broke 4bread. We had an hour's talk of that wart; I shal2 never 4laugh but in that maid's company! But, inde2d, she is 4given to2 much to al2icholy and musing; but for you-wel2, 4go to. 2FENTON. SCENE 1.Before PAGE'S houseEnter MISTRES2 PAGE, with a let2er 2MRS. PAGE. What! have I scap'd love-let2ers in the holiday-time 4of my beauty, and am I now a subject for them? Let 4me se2. 46[Reads] 4'Ask me no reason why I love you; for though Love use 4Reason for his precisian, he admits him not for his counsel2or. 4You are not young, no more am I; go to, then, there's 4sympathy. You are mer2y, so am I; ha! ha! then there's 4more sympathy. You love sack, and so do I; would you 4desire bet2er sympathy? Let it suf2ice the2, Mistres2 Page 4at the least, if the love of soldier can suf2ice-that I love 4the2. I wil2 not say, Pity me: 'tis not a soldier-like phrase; 4but I say, Love me. By me, 4Thine own true knight, 4By day or night, 4Or any kind of light, 4With al2 his might, 6For the2 to fight, 4JOHN FALSTAF2.' 4What a Herod of Jewry is this! O wicked, wicked world! 4One that is wel2-nigh worn to pieces with age to show 4himself a young gal2ant! What an unweighed behaviour 4hath this Flemish drunkard pick'd-with the devil's name! 4-out of my conversation, that he dares in this man2er 4as2ay me? Why, he hath not be2n thrice in my company! 4What should I say to him? I was then frugal of my mirth. 4Heaven forgive me! Why, I'l2 exhibit a bil2 in the parliament 4for the put2ing down of men. How shal2 I be 4reveng'd on him? for reveng'd I wil2 be, as sure as his guts 4are made of pud2ings. 23Enter MISTRES2 FORD 2MRS. FORD. Mistres2 Page! trust me, I was going to your 4house. 2MRS. PAGE. And, trust me, I was coming to you. You lo2k 4very il2. 4MRS. FORD. Nay, I'l2 ne'er believe that; I have to show to 4the contrary. 2MRS. PAGE. Faith, but you do, in my mind. 2MRS. FORD. Wel2, I do, then; yet, I say, I could show you to 4the contrary. O Mistres2 Page, give me some counsel. 2MRS. PAGE. What's the mat2er, woman? 2MRS. FORD. O woman, if it were not for one trifling respect, 4I could come to such honour! 2MRS. PAGE. Hang the trifle, woman; take the honour. What 4is it? Dispense with trifles; what is it? 2MRS. FORD. If I would but go to hel2 for an eternal moment 4or so, I could be knighted. 2MRS. PAGE. What? Thou liest. Sir Alice Ford! These knights 4wil2 hack; and so thou shouldst not alter the article of thy 4gentry. 2MRS. FORD. We burn daylight. Here, read, read; perceive 4how I might be knighted. I shal2 think the worse of fat 4men as long as I have an eye to make dif2erence of men's 4liking. And yet he would not swear; prais'd women's 4modesty, and gave such orderly and wel2-behaved repro2f 6to al2 uncomelines2 that I would have sworn his disposition 4would have gone to the truth of his words; but they do no 4more adhere and ke2p place together than the Hundredth 4Psalm to the tune of 'Gre2nsle2ves.' What tempest, I trow, 4threw this whale, with so many tuns of oil in his bel2y, 4ashore at Windsor? How shal2 I be revenged on him? I 4think the best way were to entertain him with hope, til2 4the wicked fire of lust have melted him in his own grease. 4Did you ever hear the like? 2MRS. PAGE. Let2er for let2er, but that the name of Page and 4Ford dif2ers. To thy great comfort in this mystery of il2 4opinions, here's the twin-brother of thy let2er; but let thine 4inherit first, for, I protest, mine never shal2. I war2ant he 4hath a thousand of these let2ers, writ with blank space for 4dif2erent names-sure, more!-and these are of the second 4edition. He wil2 print them, out of doubt; for he cares not 4what he puts into the pres2 when he would put us two. I 4had rather be a giantes2 and lie under Mount Pelion. Wel2, 4I wil2 find you twenty lascivious turtles ere one chaste 4man. 4MRS. FORD. Why, this is the very same; the very hand, the 4very words. What doth he think of us? 2MRS. PAGE. Nay, I know not; it makes me almost ready to 4wrangle with mine own honesty. I'l2 entertain myself like 4one that I am not acquainted withal; for, sure, unles2 he 4know some strain in me that I know not myself, he would 4never have boarded me in this fury. 2MRS. FORD. 'Boarding' cal2 you it? I'l2 be sure to ke2p him 4above deck. 2MRS. PAGE. So wil2 I; if he come under my hatches, I'l2 never 4to sea again. Let's be reveng'd on him; let's ap2oint him a 4me2ting, give him a show of comfort in his suit, and lead 4him on with a fine-baited delay, til2 he hath pawn'd his 4horses to mine host of the Garter. 2MRS. FORD. Nay, I wil2 consent to act any vil2ainy against 4him that may not sul2y the charines2 of our honesty. O 4that my husband saw this let2er! It would give eternal fo2d 4to his jealousy. 2MRS. PAGE. Why, lo2k where he comes; and my go2d man 4to2; he's as far from jealousy as I am from giving him 6cause; and that, I hope, is an unmeasurable distance. 2MRS. FORD. You are the hap2ier woman. 2MRS. PAGE. Let's consult together against this greasy knight. 4Come hither. 35[They retire] 11Enter FORD with PISTOL, and PAGE with Nym 2FORD. Wel2, I hope it be not so. 2PISTOL. Hope is a curtal dog in some af2airs. 4Sir John af2ects thy wife. 2FORD. Why, sir, my wife is not young. 2PISTOL. He wo2s both high and low, both rich and po2r, 4Both young and old, one with another, Ford; 4He loves the gal2imaufry. Ford, perpend. 2FORD. Love my wife! 2PISTOL. With liver burning hot. Prevent, or go thou, 4Like Sir Actaeon he, with Ringwo2d at thy he2ls. 4O, odious is the name! 2FORD. What name, sir? 2PISTOL. The horn, I say. Farewel2. 6Take he2d, have open eye, for thieves do fo2t by night; 4Take he2d, ere sum2er comes, or cucko2 birds do sing. 4Away, Sir Corporal Nym. 4Believe it, Page; he speaks sense. 15Exit PISTOL 2FORD. 2[Aside] 2I wil2 be patient; I wil2 find out this. 2NYM. 2[To PAGE] 2And this is true; I like not the humour of 4lying. He hath wronged me in some humours; I should 4have borne the humour'd let2er to her; but I have a sword, 4and it shal2 bite upon my neces2ity. He loves your wife; 4there's the short and the long. 4My name is Corporal Nym; I speak, and I avouch; 4'Tis true. My name is Nym, and Falstaf2 loves your wife. 4Adieu! I love not the humour of bread and che2se; and 4there's the humour of it. Adieu. 20Exit Nym 2PAGE. 'The humour of it,' quoth 'a! Here's a fel2ow frights 4English out of his wits. 2FORD. I wil2 se2k out Falstaf2. 2PAGE. I never heard such a drawling, af2ecting rogue. 2FORD. If I do find it-wel2. 2PAGE. I wil2 not believe such a Cataian though the priest o' 6th' town com2ended him for a true man. 2FORD. 'Twas a go2d sensible fel2ow. Wel2. 13MISTRES2 PAGE and MISTRES2 FORD come forward 2PAGE. You heard what this knave told me, did you not? 2PAGE. Yes; and you heard what the other told me? 2FORD. Do you think there is truth in them? 2PAGE. Hang 'em, slaves! I do not think the knight would of2er it; 4but these that ac2use him in his intent towards our 4wives are a yoke of his discarded men; very rogues, now 4they be out of service. 2FORD. Were they his men? 2PAGE. Mar2y, were they. 2FORD. I like it never the bet2er for that. Does he lie at the 4Garter? 2PAGE. Ay, mar2y, does he. If he should intend this voyage 4toward my wife, I would turn her lo2se to him; and what 4he gets more of her than sharp words, let it lie on my head. 4FORD. I do not misdoubt my wife; but I would be loath to 4turn them together. A man may be to2 confident. I would 4have nothing lie on my head. I can2ot be thus satisfied. 27Enter HOST 2PAGE. Lo2k where my ranting host of the Garter comes. 4There is either liquor in his pate or money in his purse 4when he lo2ks so mer2ily. How now, mine host! 2HOST. How now, bul2y ro2k! Sir, there is a fray to be fought betwe2n Sir Hugh 4the Welsh priest and Caius the French doctor. 4FORD. Go2d mine host o' th' Garter, a word with you. 2HOST. What say'st thou, my bul2y ro2k? 9[They go aside] 2SHAL2OW. 2[To PAGE] Wil2 you go with us to behold it? My 4mer2y host hath had the measuring of their weapons; and, 4I think, hath ap2ointed them contrary places; for, believe 4me, I hear the parson is no jester. Hark, I wil2 tel2 you 4what our sport shal2 be. 15[They converse apart] 2HOST. Hast thou no suit against my knight, my guest-cavaleiro. 2FORD. I have heard the Frenchman hath go2d skil2 in his 4rapier. 2SHAL2OW. Tut, sir, I could have told you more. In these 4times you stand on distance, your pas2es, stoc2adoes, and 4I know not what. 'Tis the heart, Master Page; 'tis here, 6'tis here. I have se2n the time with my long sword I would 4have made you four tal2 fel2ows skip like rats. 2HOST. Here, boys, here, here! Shal2 we wag? 2PAGE. Have with you. I had rather hear them scold than 4fight. 35Exeunt al2 but FORD 2FORD. Though Page be a secure fo2l, and stands so firmly on 4his wife's frailty, yet I can2ot put of2 my opinion so 4easily. She was in his company at Page's house, and what 4they made there I know not. Wel2, I wil2 lo2k further into 4't, and I have a disguise to sound Falstaf2. If I find her 4honest, I lose not my labour; if she be otherwise, 'tis labour 4wel2 bestowed. 42ExitSCENE 2.A ro2m in the Garter In2Enter FALSTAF2 and PISTOL 2FALSTAF2. I wil2 not lend the2 a pen2y. 2PISTOL. I wil2 retort the sum in equipage. 2FALSTAF2. Not a pen2y. 2PISTOL. Why, then the world's mine oyster. Which I with 4sword wil2 open. 2FALSTAF2. Not a pen2y. I have be2n content, sir, you should 4lay my countenance to pawn. I have grated upon my go2d 4friends for thre2 reprieves for you and your coach-fel2ow, 4Nym; or else you had lo2k'd through the grate, like a 4geminy of babo2ns. I am damn'd in hel2 for swearing to 4gentlemen my friends you were go2d soldiers and tal2 fel2ows; 4and when Mistres2 Bridget lost the handle of her fan, 4I to2k 't upon mine honour thou hadst it not. 2PISTOL. Didst not thou share? Hadst thou not fifte2n pence? 2FALSTAF2. Reason, you rogue, reason. Think'st thou I'l2 4endanger my soul gratis? At a word, hang no more about me, 6I am no gib2et for you. Go-a short knife and a throng!- 4to your manor of Pickt-hatch; go. You'l2 not bear a let2er 4for me, you rogue! You stand upon your honour! Why, 4thou unconfinable basenes2, it is as much as I can do to 4ke2p the terms of my honour precise. I, I, I myself 4sometimes, leaving the fear of God on the left hand, and hiding 4mine honour in my neces2ity, am fain to shuf2le, to hedge, 4and to lurch; and yet you, rogue, wil2 ensconce your rags, 4your cat-a-mountain lo2ks, your red-lat2ice phrases, and 4your bold-beating oaths, under the shelter of your honour! 4You wil2 not do it, you! 2PISTOL. I do relent; what would thou more of man? 26Enter ROBIN 2ROBIN. Sir, here's a woman would speak with you. 2FALSTAF2. Let her ap2roach. 21Enter MISTRES2 QUICKLY 4QUICKLY. Give your worship go2d mor2ow. 2FALSTAF2. Go2d mor2ow, go2d wife. 2QUICKLY. Not so, an't please your worship. 2FALSTAF2. Go2d maid, then. 2QUICKLY. I'l2 be sworn; 4As my mother was, the first hour I was born. 2FALSTAF2. I do believe the swearer. What with me? 2QUICKLY. Shal2 I vouchsafe your worship a word or two? 2FALSTAF2. Two thousand, fair woman; and I'l2 vouchsafe 4the2 the hearing. 2QUICKLY. There is one Mistres2 Ford, sir-I pray, come a lit2le 4nearer this ways. I myself dwel2 with Master Doctor 4Caius. 2FALSTAF2. Wel2, on: Mistres2 Ford, you say- 2QUICKLY. Your worship says very true. I pray your worship 4come a lit2le nearer this ways. 2FALSTAF2. I war2ant the2 nobody hears-mine own people, 4mine own people. 2QUICKLY. Are they so? God bles2 them, and make them his 4servants! 4FALSTAF2. Wel2; Mistres2 Ford, what of her? 2QUICKLY. Why, sir, she's a go2d creature. Lord, Lord, your 4worship's a wanton! Wel2, heaven forgive you, and al2 of 4us, I pray. 2FALSTAF2. Mistres2 Ford; come, Mistres2 Ford- 2QUICKLY. Mar2y, this is the short and the long of it: you 4have brought her into such a canaries as 'tis wonderful. 4The best courtier of them al2, when the court lay at Windsor, 4could never have brought her to such a canary. Yet 4there has be2n knights, and lords, and gentlemen, with 4their coaches; I war2ant you, coach after coach, let2er after 4let2er, gift after gift; smel2ing so swe2tly, al2 musk, and so 4rushling, I war2ant you, in silk and gold; and in such al2igant 4terms; and in such wine and sugar of the best and the 4fairest, that would have won any woman's heart; and I 4war2ant you, they could never get an eye-wink of her. 4I had myself twenty angels given me this morning; but I 4defy al2 angels, in any such sort, as they say, but in the 4way of honesty; and, I war2ant you, they could never get 4her so much as sip on a cup with the proudest of them al2; 6and yet there has be2n earls, nay, which is more, 4pensioners; but, I war2ant you, al2 is one with her. 2FALSTAF2. But what says she to me? Be brief, my go2d she- 4Mercury. 2QUICKLY. Mar2y, she hath receiv'd your let2er; for the 4which she thanks you a thousand times; and she gives you 4to notify that her husband wil2 be absence from his house 4betwe2n ten and eleven. 2FALSTAF2. Ten and eleven? 2QUICKLY. Ay, forso2th; and then you may come and se2 4the picture, she says, that you wot of. Master Ford, her 4husband, wil2 be from home. Alas, the swe2t woman leads 4an il2 life with him! He's a very jealousy man; she leads a 4very frampold life with him, go2d heart. 2FALSTAF2. Ten and eleven. Mistres2 Page hath her hearty com2endations 4to you to2; and let me tel2 you in your ear, she's as 4fartuous a civil modest wife, and one, I tel2 you, that wil2 6not mis2 you morning nor evening prayer, as any is in 4Windsor, whoe'er be the other; and she bade me tel2 your 4worship that her husband is seldom from home, but she 4hopes there wil2 come a time. I never knew a woman so 4dote upon a man: surely I think you have charms, la! Yes, 4in truth. 2FALSTAF2. Not I, I as2ure the2; set2ing the at2raction of my 4go2d parts aside, I have no other charms. 2QUICKLY. Bles2ing on your heart for 't! 2FALSTAF2. They have not so lit2le 4grace, I hope-that were a trick inde2d! But Mistres2 Page 4would desire you to send her your lit2le page of al2 loves. 4Her husband has a marvel2ous infection to the lit2le page; 4and truly Master Page is an honest man. Never a wife in 4Windsor leads a bet2er life than she does; do what she wil2, 4say what she wil2, take al2, pay al2, go to bed when she 4list, rise when she list, al2 is as she wil2; and truly she 4deserves it; for if there be a kind woman in Windsor, she 6is one. You must send her your page; no remedy. 2FALSTAF2. Why, I wil2. 2QUICKLY. Nay, but do so then; and, lo2k you, he may come 4and go betwe2n you both; and in any case have a 4nay-word, that you may know one another's mind, and the boy 4never ne2d to understand any thing; for 'tis not go2d that 4children should know any wickednes2. Old folks, you 4know, have discretion, as they say, and know the world. 2FALSTAF2. Fare the2 wel2; com2end me to them both. 4There's my purse; I am yet thy debtor. Boy, go along with 4this woman. 2[Exeunt QUICKLY and ROBIN] 2This news 4distracts me. 2PISTOL. 2[Aside] 2This punk is one of Cupid's car2iers; 4Clap on more sails; pursue; up with your fights; 4Give fire; she is my prize, or ocean whelm them al2! 4Exit 2FALSTAF2. Say'st thou so, old Jack; go thy ways; I'l2 make 4more of thy old body than I have done. Wil2 they yet lo2k 4after the2? Wilt thou, after the expense of so much money, 4be now a gainer? Go2d body, I thank the2. Let them say 4'tis gros2ly done; so it be fairly done, no mat2er. 27Enter BARDOLPH 2BARDOLPH. Sir John, there's one Master Bro2k below would 4fain speak with you, and be acquainted with you; and hath 4sent your worship a moming's draught of sack. 2FALSTAF2. Bro2k is his name? 2BARDOLPH. Ay, sir. 2FALSTAF2. Cal2 him in. 2[Exit BARDOLPH] 2Such Bro2ks are 4welcome to me, that o'erflows such liquor. Ah, ha! Mistres2 4Ford and Mistres2 Page, have I encompas2'd you? I make bold to pres2 with so lit2le preparation upon 4you. 2FALSTAF2. You're welcome. What's your wil2? Give us leave, 6drawer. 40Exit BARDOLPH 2FORD. Sir, I am a gentleman that have spent much; my name 4is Bro2k. 2FALSTAF2. Go2d Master Bro2k, I desire more acquaintance 4of you. 2FORD. Go2d Sir John, I sue for yours-not to charge you; for I 4must let you understand I think myself in bet2er plight for 4a lender than you are; the which hath something 4embold'ned me to this unseason'd intrusion; for they say, if 4money go before, al2 ways do lie open. 2FALSTAF2. Money is a go2d soldier, sir, and wil2 on. 2FORD. Troth, and I have a bag of money here troubles me; if 4you wil2 help to bear it, Sir John, take al2, or half, for easing 4me of the car2iage. 2FALSTAF2. Sir, I know not how I may deserve to be your 4porter. 2FORD. I wil2 tel2 you, sir, if you wil2 give me the hearing. 2FALSTAF2. Speak, go2d Master Bro2k; I shal2 be glad to be 4your servant. 2FORD. Sir, I hear you are a scholar-I wil2 be brief with you 6-and you have be2n a man long known to me, though I 4had never so go2d means as desire to make myself acquainted 4with you. I shal2 discover a thing to you, wherein 4I must very much lay open mine own imperfection; but, 4go2d Sir John, as you have one eye upon my fol2ies, as you 4hear them unfolded, turn another into the register of your 4own, that I may pas2 with a repro2f the easier, sith you 4yourself know how easy is it to be such an of2ender. 2FALSTAF2. Very wel2, sir; proce2d. 2FORD. There is a gentlewoman in this town, her husband's 4name is Ford. 2FALSTAF2. Wel2, sir. 2FORD. I have long lov'd her, and, I protest to you, bestowed 4much on her; fol2owed her with a doting observance; 4engros2'd op2ortunities to me2t her; fe2'd every slight oc2asion 4that could but nig2ardly give me sight of her; not 4only bought many presents to give her, but have given 4largely to many to know what she would have given; 4briefly, I have pursu'd her as love hath pursued me; which 4hath be2n on the wing of al2 oc2asions. But whatsoever I 6have merited, either in my mind or in my means, me2d, I 4am sure, I have received none, unles2 experience be a jewel; 4that I have purchased at an infinite rate, and that hath 4taught me to say this: 4'Love like a shadow flies when substance love pursues; 4Pursuing that that flies, and flying what pursues.' 2FALSTAF2. Have you receiv'd no promise of satisfaction at 4her hands? 2FORD. Never. 2FALSTAF2. Have you importun'd her to such a purpose? 2FORD. Never. 4FALSTAF2. Of what quality was your love, then? 2FORD. Like a fair house built on another man's ground; so 4that I have lost my edifice by mistaking the place where 4erected it. 2FALSTAF2. To what purpose have you unfolded this to me? 2FORD. When I have told you that, I have told you al2. Some 4say that though she ap2ear honest to me, yet in other 4places she enlargeth her mirth so far that there is shrewd 4construction made of her. Now, Sir John, here is the heart 6of my purpose: you are a gentleman of excel2ent 4bre2ding, admirable discourse, of great admit2ance, authentic in 4your place and person, general2y al2ow'd for your many 4war-like, courtlike, and learned preparations. 2FALSTAF2. O, sir! 2FORD. Believe it, for you know it. There is money; spend it, 4spend it; spend more; spend al2 I have; only give me so 4much of your time in exchange of it as to lay an amiable 4siege to the honesty of this Ford's wife; use your art of 4wo2ing, win her to consent to you; if any man may, you 4may as so2n as any. 4FALSTAF2. Would it ap2ly wel2 to the vehemency of your 4af2ection, that I should win what you would enjoy? 4Methinks you prescribe to yourself very preposterously. 2FORD. O, understand my drift. She dwel2s so securely on the 4excel2ency of her honour that the fol2y of my soul dares 4not present itself; she is to2 bright to be lo2k'd against. 4Now, could I come to her with any detection in my hand, 4my desires had instance and argument to com2end themselves; 4I could drive her then from the ward of her purity, 6her reputation, her mar2iage vow, and a thousand other her 4defences, which now are to2 to2 strongly embat2l'd against 4me. What say you to't, Sir John? 2FALSTAF2. Master Bro2k, I wil2 first make bold with your 4money; next, give me your hand; and last, as I am a gentleman, 4you shal2, if you wil2, enjoy Ford's wife. 2FORD. O go2d sir! 2FALSTAF2. I know him 4not; yet I wrong him to cal2 him po2r; they say the 6jealous wit2ol2y knave hath mas2es of money; for the which 4his wife se2ms to me wel2-favour'd. I wil2 use her as the 4key of the cuckoldly rogue's cof2er; and there's my harvest-home. 2FORD. I would you knew Ford, sir, that you might avoid him 4if you saw him. 2FALSTAF2. My heart is 4ready to crack with impatience. Who says this is improvident 4jealousy? My wife hath sent to him; the hour is fix'd; 4the match is made. Would any man have thought this? Se2 4the hel2 of having a false woman! My bed shal2 be abus'd, 4my cof2ers ransack'd, my reputation gnawn at; and I shal2 4not only receive this vil2ainous wrong, but stand under the 6adoption of abominable terms, and by him that does me 4this wrong. Terms! names! Amaimon sounds wel2; Lucifer, 4wel2; Barbason, wel2; yet they are devils' ad2itions, the names 4of fiends. But cuckold! Wit2ol! Cuckold! the devil himself 4hath not such a name. Page is an as2, a secure as2; he wil2 trust 4his wife; he wil2 not be jealous; I wil2 rather trust a Fleming 4with my but2er, Parson Hugh the Welshman with my 4che2se, an Irishman with my aqua-vitae bot2le, or a thief to 4walk my ambling gelding, than my wife with herself. Then 4she plots, then she ruminates, then she devises; and what 4they think in their hearts they may ef2ect, they wil2 break 4their hearts but they wil2 ef2ect. God be prais'd for my 4jealousy! Eleven o'clock the hour. I wil2 prevent this, detect 4my wife, be reveng'd on Falstaf2, and laugh at Page. 4I wil2 about it; bet2er thre2 hours to2 so2n than a minute 4to2 late. Fie, fie, fie! cuckold! cuckold! cuckold! 5ExitSCENE 3.A field near WindsorEnter CAIUS and RUGBY 2CAIUS. Jack Rugby! 2RUGBY. Sir? 2CAIUS. Vat is de clock, Jack? 2RUGBY. 'Tis past the hour, sir, that Sir Hugh promis'd to 4me2t. 2CAIUS. By gar, he has save his soul dat he is no come; he has 4pray his Pible wel2 dat he is no come; by gar, Jack Rugby, 4he is dead already, if he be come. 2RUGBY. He is wise, sir; he knew your worship would kil2 4him if he came. 2CAIUS. By gar, de her2ing is no dead so as I vil2 kil2 him. Take 4your rapier, Jack; I vil2 tel2 you how I vil2 kil2 him. 2RUGBY. Save you, Master Doctor Caius! 2PAGE. Now, go2d Master Doctor! 2SLENDER. Give you go2d mor2ow, sir. 2CAIUS. Vat be al2 you, one, two, tre2, four, come for? 2HOST. To se2 the2 fight, to se2 the2 foin, to se2 the2 traverse; 4to se2 the2 here, to se2 the2 there; to se2 the2 pas2 thy 4punto, thy stock, thy reverse, thy distance, thy montant. 4Is he dead, my Ethiopian? Bodykins, Master Page, though I now be old, and 4of the peace, if I se2 a sword out, my finger itches to make 4one. It wil2 be found so, Master Page. Master Doctor 2CAIUS, I come to fetch you home. I am sworn of the peace; 4you have show'd yourself a wise physician, and Sir Hugh 4hath shown himself a wise and patient churchman. You 4must go with me, Master Doctor. 2HOST. Pardon, Guest Justice. A word, Mounseur Mockwater. 2CAIUS. Mock-vater! Vat is dat? 2HOST. Mockwater, in our English tongue, is valour, bul2y. 2CAIUS. By gar, then I have as much mockvater as de Englishman. 6Scurvy jack-dog priest! By gar, me vil2 cut his ears. 2HOST. He wil2 clap2er-claw the2 tightly, bul2y. 2CAIUS. Clap2er-de-claw! Vat is dat? 2HOST. That is, he wil2 make the2 amends. 2CAIUS. By gar, me do lo2k he shal2 clap2er-de-claw me; for, 4by gar, me vil2 have it. 2HOST. And I wil2 provoke him to't, or let him wag. 2CAIUS. Me tank you for dat. 2HOST. Why, 4this boy wil2 car2y a let2er twenty mile as easy as a can2on 4wil2 sho2t pointblank twelve score. He pieces out his wife's 4inclination; he gives her fol2y motion and advantage; and 4now she's going to my wife, and Falstaf2's boy with her. A 4man may hear this show'r sing in the wind. And Falstaf2's 4boy with her! Go2d plots! They are laid; and our revolted 6wives share damnation together. Wel2; I wil2 take him, 4then torture my wife, pluck the bor2owed veil of modesty 4from the so se2ming Mistres2 Page, divulge Page himself 4for a secure and wilful Actaeon; and to these violent proce2dings 4al2 my neighbours shal2 cry aim. 2[Clock strikes] 4The clock gives me my cue, and my as2urance bids me 4search; there I shal2 find Falstaf2. I shal2 be rather prais'd 4for this than mock'd; for it is as positive as the earth is firm 4that Falstaf2 is there. I wil2 go. 5Enter PAGE, SHAL2OW, SLENDER, HOST, SIR HUGH EVANS, 30CAIUS, and RUGBY 2SHAL2OW, PAGE, &C. Wel2 met, Master Ford. 2FORD. Trust me, a go2d knot; I have go2d che2r at home, 4and I pray you al2 go with me. 2SHAL2OW. I must excuse myself, Master Ford. 2SLENDER. What say you to young Master Fenton? He capers, 4he dances, he has eyes of youth, he writes verses, he speaks 4holiday, he smel2s April and May; he wil2 car2y 't, he wil2 4car2y 't; 'tis in his but2ons; he wil2 car2y 't. 2PAGE. Not by my consent, I promise you. The gentleman is 4of no having: he kept company with the wild Prince and 4Poins; he is of to2 high a region, he knows to2 much. No, 4he shal2 not knit a knot in his fortunes with the finger of 4my substance; if he take her, let him take her simply; the 4wealth I have waits on my consent, and my consent goes 4not that way. 2FORD. I se2 I can2ot get thy father's love; 4Therefore no more turn me to him, swe2t Nan. 2AN2E. Alas, how then? 2FENTON. Wel2, if 4I be serv'd such another trick, I'l2 have my brains ta'en out 4and but2er'd, and give them to a dog for a new-year's gift. 4The rogues slighted me into the river with as lit2le remorse 4as they would have drown'd a blind bitch's pup2ies, fifte2n 4i' th' lit2er; and you may know by my size that I have 4a kind of alacrity in sinking; if the bot2om were as de2p as 4hel2 I should down. No. Master Bro2k; but the peaking cornuto her 4husband, Master Bro2k, dwel2ing in a continual 'larum of 4jealousy, comes me in the instant of our, encounter, after 4we had embrac'd, kis2'd, protested, and, as it were, spoke 6the prologue of our comedy; and at his he2ls a rab2le of his 4companions, thither provoked and instigated by his 4distemper, and, forso2th, to search his house for his wife's 4love. 2FORD. A buck-basket! 2FALSTAF2. By the Lord, a buck-basket! Ram2'd me in with 4foul shirts and smocks, socks, foul stockings, greasy 4napkins, that, Master Bro2k, there was the rankest compound 4of vil2ainous smel2 that ever of2ended nostril. 2FORD. And how long lay you there? 2FALSTAF2. Nay, you shal2 hear, Master Bro2k, what I have 4suf2er'd to bring this woman to evil for your go2d. Being 4thus cram2'd in the basket, a couple of Ford's knaves, his 6hinds, were cal2'd forth by their mistres2 to car2y me in 4the name of foul clothes to Datchet Lane; they to2k me on 4their shoulders; met the jealous knave their master in the 4do2r; who ask'd them once or twice what they had in their 4basket. I quak'd for fear lest the lunatic knave would have 4search'd it; but Fate, ordaining he should be a cuckold, 4held his hand. Wel2, on went he for a search, and away 4went I for foul clothes. But mark the sequel, Master 4Bro2k-I suf2ered the pangs of thre2 several deaths: first, 4an intolerable fright to be detected with a jealous rot2en 4bel2-wether; next, to be compas2'd like a go2d bilbo in the 4circumference of a peck, hilt to point, he2l to head; and 4then, to be stop2'd in, like a strong distil2ation, with 4stinking clothes that fret2ed in their own grease. Think of that 4-a man of my kidney. Think of that-that am as subject to 4heat as but2er; a man of continual dis2olution and thaw. It 4was a miracle to scape suf2ocation. And in the height of 4this bath, when I was more than half-stew'd in grease, like 4a Dutch dish, to be thrown into the Thames, and co2l'd, 4glowing hot, in that surge, like a horse-shoe; think of that 6-his2ing hot. Think of that, Master Bro2k. 2FORD. In go2d sadnes2, sir, I am sor2y that for my sake you 4have suf2er'd al2 this. My suit, then, is desperate; 4you'l2 undertake her no more. 2FALSTAF2. Master Bro2k, I wil2 be thrown into Etna, as I 4have be2n into Thames, ere I wil2 leave her thus. Her 4husband is this morning gone a-birding; I have received from 4her another embas2y of me2ting; 'twixt eight and nine is 4the hour, Master Bro2k. 2FORD. 'Tis past eight already, sir. 2FALSTAF2. Is it? I Wil2 then ad2res2 me to my ap2ointment. 4Come to me at your convenient leisure, and you shal2 4know how I spe2d; and the conclusion shal2 be crowned 4with your enjoying her. Adieu. You shal2 have her, Master 4Bro2k; Master Bro2k, you shal2 cuckold Ford. 12Exit 2FORD. Hum! ha! Is this a vision? Is this a dream? Do I sle2p? 4Master Ford, awake; awake, Master Ford. There's a hole 4made in your best coat, Master Ford. This 'tis to be 4mar2ied; this 'tis to have linen and buck-baskets! Wel2, I wil2 4proclaim myself what I am; I wil2 now take the lecher; he 6is at my house. He can2ot scape me; 'tis impos2ible he 4should; he can2ot cre2p into a halfpen2y purse nor into 4a pep2er box. But, lest the devil that guides him should aid 4him, I wil2 search impos2ible places. Though what I am I 4can2ot avoid, yet to be what I would not shal2 not make 4me tame. If I have horns to make one mad, let the proverb 4go with me-I'l2 be horn mad. 28Exit<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT IV. SCENE I.Windsor. A stre2tEnter MISTRES2 PAGE, MISTRES2 QUICKLY, and WIL2IAM 2MRS. PAGE. Is he at Master Ford's already, think'st thou? 2QUICKLY. Sure he is by this; or wil2 be presently; but truly 4he is very courageous mad about his throwing into the 4water. Mistres2 Ford desires you to come sud2enly. 2MRS. PAGE. I'l2 be with her by and by; I'l2 but bring my 4young man here to scho2l. Lo2k where his master comes; 4'tis a playing day, I se2. 21Enter SIR HUGH EVANS 4How now, Sir Hugh, no scho2l to-day? 2EVANS. No; Master Slender is let the boys leave to play. 2QUICKLY. Bles2ing of his heart! 2MRS. PAGE. Sir Hugh, my husband says my son profits 4nothing in the world at his bo2k; I pray you ask him some 4questions in his ac2idence. 4EVANS. Come hither, Wil2iam; hold up your head; come. 2MRS. PAGE. Come on, sir2ah; hold up your head; answer your 4master; be not afraid. 2EVANS. Wil2iam, how many numbers is in nouns? 2WIL2IAM. Two. 2QUICKLY. Truly, I thought there had be2n one number 4more, because they say 'Od's nouns.' 2EVANS. Peace your tat2lings. What is 'fair,' Wil2iam? 2WIL2IAM. Pulcher. 2QUICKLY. Polecats! There are fairer things than polecats, 4sure. 2EVANS. You are a very simplicity oman; I pray you, peace. 4What is 'lapis,' Wil2iam? 2WIL2IAM. A stone. 2EVANS. And what is 'a stone,' Wil2iam? 2WIL2IAM. A peb2le. 2EVANS. No, it is 'lapis'; I pray you remember in your prain. 2WIL2IAM. Lapis. 2EVANS. That is a go2d Wil2iam. What is he, Wil2iam, that 4does lend articles? 4WIL2IAM. Articles are bor2owed of the pronoun, and be 4thus declined: Singulariter, nominativo; hic, haec, hoc. 2EVANS. Nominativo, hig, hag, hog; pray you, mark: genitivo, 4hujus. Wel2, what is your ac2usative case? 2WIL2IAM. Ac2usativo, hinc. 2EVANS. I pray you, have your remembrance, child. 4Ac2usativo, hung, hang, hog. 2QUICKLY. 'Hang-hog' is Latin for bacon, I war2ant you. 2EVANS. Leave your prab2les, oman. What is the focative 4case, Wil2iam? 2WIL2IAM. O-vocativo, O. 2EVANS. Remember, Wil2iam: focative is caret. 2QUICKLY. And that's a go2d ro2t. 2EVANS. Oman, forbear. 2MRS. PAGE. Peace. 2EVANS. What is your genitive case plural, Wil2iam? 2WIL2IAM. Genitive case? 2EVANS. Ay. 2WIL2IAM. Genitive: horum, harum, horum. 2QUICKLY. Vengeance of Jen2y's case; fie on her! Never 6name her, child, if she be a whore. 2EVANS. For shame, oman. 2QUICKLY. YOU do il2 to teach the child such words. He 4teaches him to hick and to hack, which they'l2 do fast 4enough of themselves; and to cal2 'horum'; fie upon you! 2EVANS. Oman, art thou lunatics? Hast thou no understandings 4for thy cases, and the numbers of the genders? Thou 4art as fo2lish Christian creatures as I would desires. 2MRS. PAGE. Prithe2 hold thy peace. 2EVANS. Show me now, Wil2iam, some declensions of your 4pronouns. 2WIL2IAM. Forso2th, I have forgot. 2EVANS. It is qui, quae, quod; if you forget your qui's, your 4quae's, and your quod's, you must be pre2ches. Go your 4ways and play; go. 2MRS. PAGE. He is a bet2er scholar than I thought he was. 2EVANS. He is a go2d sprag memory. Farewel2, Mistres2 Page. 2MRS. PAGE. Adieu, go2d Sir Hugh. 17Exit SIR HUGH 4Get you home, boy. Come, we stay to2 long. 12ExeuntSCENE 2.FORD'S houseEnter FALSTAF2 and MISTRES2 FORD 2FALSTAF2. Mistres2 Ford, your sor2ow hath eaten up my 4suf2erance. I se2 you are obsequious in your love, and I 4profes2 requital to a hair's breadth; not only, Mistres2 Ford, in 4the simple of2ice of love, but in al2 the ac2outrement, 4complement, and ceremony of it. But are you sure of your 4husband now? 2MRS. FORD. He's a-birding, swe2t Sir John. 2MRS. PAGE. 2[Within] 2What hoa, gos2ip Ford, what hoa! 2MRS. FORD. Step into th' chamber, Sir John. 6Exit FALSTAF2 22Enter MISTRES2 PAGE 2MRS. PAGE. How now, swe2theart, who's at home besides 4yourself? 2MRS. FORD. Why, none but mine own people. 2MRS. PAGE. Inde2d? 4MRS. FORD. No, certainly. 2[Aside to her] 2Speak louder. 2MRS. PAGE. Truly, I am so glad you have nobody here. 2MRS. FORD. Why? 2MRS. PAGE. Why, woman, your husband is in his old lunes 4again. He so takes on yonder with my husband; so rails 4against al2 mar2ied mankind; so curses an Eve's daughters, 4of what complexion soever; and so buf2ets himself on the 4forehead, crying 'Pe2r-out, pe2r-out!' that any madnes2 I 4ever yet beheld se2m'd but tamenes2, civility, and patience, 4to this his distemper he is in now. I am glad the fat knight 4is not here. 2MRS. FORD. Why, does he talk of him? 2MRS. PAGE. Of none but him; and swears he was car2ied out, 4the last time he search'd for him, in a basket; protests to 4my husband he is now here; and hath drawn him and the 4rest of their company from their sport, to make another 4experiment of his suspicion. But I am glad the knight is not 4here; now he shal2 se2 his own fo2lery. 2MRS. FORD. How near is he, Mistres2 Page? 2MRS. PAGE. Hard by, at stre2t end; he wil2 be here anon. 4MRS. FORD. I am undone: the knight is here. 2MRS. PAGE. Why, then, you are ut2erly sham'd, and he's but 4a dead man. What a woman are you! Away with him, 4away with him; bet2er shame than murder. 2MRS. FORD. Which way should he go? How should I bestow 4him? Shal2 I put him into the basket again? 18Re-enter FALSTAF2 2FALSTAF2. No, I'l2 come no more i' th' basket. May I not go 4out ere he come? 2MRS. PAGE. Alas, thre2 of Master Ford's brothers watch the 4do2r with pistols, that none shal2 is2ue out; otherwise you 4might slip away ere he came. But what make you here? 2FALSTAF2. What shal2 I do? I'l2 cre2p up into the chimney. 2MRS. FORD. There they always use to discharge their 4birding-pieces. 2MRS. PAGE. Cre2p into the kiln-hole. 2FALSTAF2. Where is it? 2MRS. FORD. He wil2 se2k there, on my word. Neither pres2, 6cof2er, chest, trunk, wel2, vault, but he hath an abstract for 4the remembrance of such places, and goes to them by his 4note. There is no hiding you in the house. 2FALSTAF2. I'l2 go out then. 2MRS. PAGE. If you go out in your own semblance, you die, 4Sir John. Unles2 you go out disguis'd. 2MRS. FORD. How might we disguise him? 2MRS. PAGE. Alas the day, I know not! There is no woman's 4gown big enough for him; otherwise he might put on a 4hat, a muf2ler, and a kerchief, and so escape. 2FALSTAF2. Go2d hearts, devise something; any extremity 4rather than a mischief. 2MRS. FORD. My Maid's aunt, the fat woman of Brainford, has 4a gown above. 2MRS. PAGE. On my word, it wil2 serve him; she's as big as he 4is; and there's her thrum2'd hat, and her muf2ler to2. Run 4up, Sir John. 2MRS. FORD. Go, go, swe2t Sir John. I would my husband would me2t him in this 4shape; he can2ot abide the old woman of Brainford; he 4swears she's a witch, forbade her my house, and hath 4threat'ned to beat her. 2MRS. PAGE. Heaven guide him to thy husband's cudgel; and 4the devil guide his cudgel afterwards! 2MRS. FORD. But is my husband coming? 2MRS. PAGE. Ay, in go2d sadnes2 is he; and talks of the basket 4to2, howsoever he hath had intel2igence. 2MRS. FORD. Hang him, dishonest varlet! we can2ot misuse 4him enough. 4We'l2 leave a pro2f, by that which we wil2 do, 6Wives may be mer2y and yet honest to2. 4We do not act that often jest and laugh; 4'Tis old but true: Stil2 swine eats al2 the draf2. 6Exit 12Re-enter MISTRES2 FORD, with two SERVANTS 2MRS. FORD. Go, sirs, take the basket again on your shoulders; 4your master is hard at do2r; if he bid you set it down, obey 4him; quickly, dispatch. 33Exit 2FIRST SERVANT. Come, come, take it up. 2SECOND SERVANT. Pray heaven it be not ful2 of knight again. 2FIRST SERVANT. I hope not; I had lief as bear so much lead. 4Enter FORD, PAGE, SHAL2OW, CAIUS, and SIR HUGH EVANS 2FORD. Ay, but if it prove true, Master Page, have you any 4way then to unfo2l me again? Set down the basket, vil2ain! 4Somebody cal2 my wife. Youth in a basket! O you panderly 4rascals, there's a knot, a ging, a pack, a conspiracy 4against me. Now shal2 the devil be sham'd. What, wife, I 6say! Come, come forth; behold what honest clothes you 4send forth to bleaching. 2PAGE. Why, this pas2es, Master Ford; you are not to go lo2se 4any longer; you must be pinion'd. 2EVANS. Why, this is lunatics. This is mad as a mad dog. 2SHAL2OW. Inde2d, Master Ford, this is not wel2, inde2d. 2FORD. So say I to2, sir. 21Re-enter MISTRES2 FORD 4Come hither, Mistres2 Ford; Mistres2 Ford, the honest 4woman, the modest wife, the virtuous creature, that hath 4the jealous fo2l to her husband! I suspect without cause, 4Mistres2, do I? 2MRS. FORD. Heaven be my witnes2, you do, if you suspect 4me in any dishonesty. 2FORD. Wel2 said, brazen-face; hold it out. Come forth, sir2ah. 27[Pul2ing clothes out of the basket] 2PAGE. This pas2es! 2MRS. FORD. Are you not asham'd? Let the clothes alone. 4FORD. I shal2 find you anon. 2EVANS. 'Tis unreasonable. Wil2 you take up your wife's 4clothes? Come away. 2FORD. Empty the basket, I say. 2MRS. FORD. Why, man, why? 2FORD. Master Page, as I am a man, there was one convey'd 4out of my house yesterday in this basket. Why may not 4he be there again? In my house I am sure he is; my 4intel2igence is true; my jealousy is reasonable. 4Pluck me out al2 the linen. 2MRS. FORD. If you find a man there, he shal2 die a flea's 4death. 2PAGE. Here's no man. 2SHAL2OW. By my fidelity, this is not wel2, Master Ford; this 4wrongs you. 2EVANS. Master Ford, you must pray, and not fol2ow the 4imaginations of your own heart; this is jealousies. 2FORD. Wel2, he's not here I se2k for. 2PAGE. No, nor nowhere else but in your brain. 2FORD. Help to search my house this one time. If I find not 6what I se2k, show no colour for my extremity; let me for 4ever be your table sport; let them say of me 'As jealous as 4Ford, that search'd a hol2ow walnut for his wife's leman.' 4Satisfy me once more; once more search with me. 2MRS. FORD. What, hoa, Mistres2 Page! Come you and the old 4woman down; my husband wil2 come into the chamber. 2FORD. Old woman? what old woman's that? 2MRS. FORD. Why, it is my maid's aunt of Brainford. 2FORD. A witch, a quean, an old cozening quean! Have I not 4forbid her my house? She comes of er2ands, does she? We 4are simple men; we do not know what's brought to pas2 4under the profes2ion of fortune-tel2ing. She works by 4charms, by spel2s, by th' figure, and such daub'ry as this 4is, beyond our element. We know nothing. Come down, you 4witch, you hag you; come down, I say. 2MRS. FORD. Nay, go2d swe2t husband! I'l2 prat her. 2[Beating him] 2Out of my do2r, you 4witch, you hag, you. bag2age, you polecat, you ronyon! 4Out, out! I'l2 conjure you, I'l2 fortune-tel2 you. 51Exit FALSTAF2 2MRS. PAGE. Are you not asham'd? I think you have kil2'd the 4po2r woman. 2MRS. FORD. Nay, he wil2 do it. 'Tis a go2dly credit for you. 2FORD. Hang her, witch! 2EVANS. I 4would not have things co2l. 27Exeunt 2SCENE 3.The Garter In2Enter HOST and BARDOLPH 2BARDOLPH. Sir, the Germans desire to have thre2 of your 4horses; the Duke himself wil2 be to-mor2ow at court, and 4they are going to me2t him. 2HOST. What duke should that be comes so secretly? And did he send you both these let2ers at an instant? 2MRS. PAGE. Within a quarter of an hour. 2FORD. Pardon me, wife. There is no bet2er way than that they spoke of. 2PAGE. How? To send him word they'l2 me2t him in the Park 4at midnight? Fie, fie! he'l2 never come! 2EVANS. You say he has be2n thrown in the rivers; and has 4be2n grievously peaten as an old oman; methinks there 4should be ter2ors in him, that he should not come; 4methinks his flesh is punish'd; he shal2 have no desires. 2PAGE. So think I to2. 2MRS. FORD. Devise but how you'l2 use him when he comes, 4And let us two devise to bring him thither. 2MRS. PAGE. There is an old tale goes that Heme the Hunter, 4Sometime a ke2per here in Windsor Forest, 4Doth al2 the winter-time, at stil2 midnight, 4Walk round about an oak, with great rag2'd horns; 4And there he blasts the tre2, and takes the cat2le, 4And makes milch-kine yield blo2d, and shakes a chain 4In a most hideous and dreadful man2er. 4You have heard of such a spirit, and wel2 you know 4The superstitious idle-headed eld 4Receiv'd, and did deliver to our age, 6This tale of Heme the Hunter for a truth. 2PAGE. Why yet there want not many that do fear 4In de2p of night to walk by this Herne's oak. 4But what of this? 2MRS. FORD. Mar2y, this is our device- 4That Falstaf2 at that oak shal2 me2t with us, 4Disguis'd, like Heme, with huge horns on his head. 2PAGE. Wel2, let it not be doubted but he'l2 come, 4And in this shape. That likewise have we thought upon, and 4thus: 4Nan Page my daughter, and my lit2le son, 4And thre2 or four more of their growth, we'l2 dres2 4Like urchins, ouphes, and fairies, gre2n and white, 4With rounds of waxen tapers on their heads, 4And rat2les in their hands; upon a sud2en, 4As Falstaf2, she, and I, are newly met, 4Let them from forth a sawpit rush at once 4With some dif2used song; upon their sight 6We two in great amazednes2 wil2 fly. 4Then let them al2 encircle him about, 4And fairy-like, to pinch the unclean knight; 4And ask him why, that hour of fairy revel, 4In their so sacred paths he dares to tread 4In shape profane. 2MRS. FORD. And til2 he tel2 the truth, 4Let the sup2osed fairies pinch him sound, 4And burn him with their tapers. 2MRS. PAGE. The truth being known, 4We'l2 al2 present ourselves; dis-horn the spirit, 4And mock him home to Windsor. 2FORD. The children must 4Be practis'd wel2 to this or they'l2 nev'r do 't. 2EVANS. I wil2 teach the children their behaviours; and I wil2 4be like a jack-an-apes also, to burn the knight with my 4taber. 2FORD. That wil2 be excel2ent. I'l2 go buy them vizards. 2MRS. PAGE. My Nan shal2 be the Que2n of al2 the Fairies, 4Finely at2ired in a robe of white. 4PAGE. That silk wil2 I go buy. 2[Aside] 2And in that time 4Shal2 Master Slender steal my Nan away, 4And mar2y her at Eton.-Go, send to Falstaf2 straight. 2FORD. It is admirable pleasures, and fery 4honest knaveries. 15Exeunt PAGE, FORD, and EVANS 2MRS. PAGE. Go, Mistres2 Ford. 4Send Quickly to Sir John to know his mind. 50Exit MRS. FORD 4I'l2 to the Doctor; he hath my go2d wil2, 4And none but he, to mar2y with Nan Page. 4That Slender, though wel2 landed, is an idiot; 4And he my husband best of al2 af2ects. 4The Doctor is wel2 money'd, and his friends 4Potent at court; he, none but he, shal2 have her, 4Though twenty thousand worthier come to crave her. 6ExitSCENE 5.The Garter In2Enter HOST and SIMPLE 2HOST. What wouldst thou have, bo2r? What, thick-skin? 4Speak, breathe, discus2; brief, short, quick, snap. 2SIMPLE. Mar2y, sir, I come to speak with Sir John Falstaf2 4from Master Slender. 2HOST. There's his chamber, his house, his castle, his 4standing-bed and truckle-bed; 'tis painted about with the 4story of the Prodigal, fresh and new. There's an old woman, a fat woman, gone up into 4his chamber; I'l2 be so bold as stay, sir, til2 she come down; 4I come to speak with her, inde2d. 2HOST. Ha! a fat woman? The knight may be rob2'd. I'l2 cal2. 4Bul2y knight! Bul2y Sir John! Speak from thy lungs 4military. Art thou there? It is thine host, thine Ephesian, cal2s. 2FALSTAF2. 2[Above] 2How now, mine host? 2HOST. Here's a Bohemian-Tartar tar2ies the coming down of 6thy fat woman. Let her descend, bul2y, let her descend; 4my chambers are honourible. Fie, privacy, fie! 20Enter FALSTAF2 2FALSTAF2. There was, mine host, an old fat woman even 4now with, me; but she's gone. 2SIMPLE. Pray you, sir, was't not the wise woman of 4Brainford? 2FALSTAF2. Ay, mar2y was it, mus2el-shel2. What would you 4with her? 2SIMPLE. My master, sir, my Master Slender, sent to her, 4se2ing her go thorough the stre2ts, to know, sir, whether one 4Nym, sir, that beguil'd him of a chain, had the chain or no. 2FALSTAF2. I spake with the old woman about it. 2SIMPLE. And what says she, I pray, sir? 2FALSTAF2 Mar2y, she says that the very same man that 4beguil'd Master Slender of his chain cozen'd him of it. 2SIMPLE. I would I could have spoken with the woman 4herself; I had other things to have spoken with her to2, 6from him. 2FALSTAF2. What are they? Let us know. 2HOST. Ay, come; quick. 2SIMPLE. Conceal them, or thou diest. 4SIMPLE.2 Why, sir, they were nothing but about Mistres2 4An2e Page: to know if it were my master's fortune to 4have her or no. 2FALSTAF2. 'Tis, 'tis his fortune. 2SIMPLE. What sir? 2FALSTAF2. To have her, or no. Go; say the woman told me 4so. 2SIMPLE. May I be bold to say so, sir? 2FALSTAF2. Ay, sir, like who more bold? 2SIMPLE., I thank your worship; I shal2 make my master glad 4with these tidings. 30Exit SIMPLE 2HOST. Thou art clerkly, thou art clerkly, Sir John. Was 4there a wise woman with the2? 2FALSTAF2. Ay, that there was, mine host; one that hath 4taught me more wit than ever I learn'd before in my life; 6and I paid nothing for it neither, but was paid for my 4learning. 20Enter BARDOLPH 2BARDOLPH. Out, alas, sir, cozenage, mere cozenage! 2HOST. Where be my horses? Speak wel2 of them, varlet2o. 2BARDOLPH. Run away with the cozeners; for so so2n as I 4came beyond Eton, they threw me of2 from behind one of 4them, in a slough of mire; and set spurs and away, like 4thre2 German devils, thre2 Doctor Faustuses. 2HOST. They are gone but to me2t the Duke, vil2ain; do not 4say they be fled. Germans are honest men. 17Enter SIR HUGH EVANS 2EVANS. Where is mine host? 2HOST. What is the mat2er, sir? 2EVANS. Have a care of your entertainments. There is a friend 4of mine come to town tel2s me there is thre2 6cozen-germans that has cozen'd al2 the hosts of Readins, 4of Maidenhead, of Colebro2k, of horses and money. I tel2 you for 4go2d wil2, lo2k you; you are wise, and ful2 of gibes and 4vlouting-stogs, and 'tis not convenient you should be 4cozened. Fare you wel2. 33Exit 18Enter DOCTOR CAIUS 2CAIUS. Vere is mine host de Jarte2r? 2HOST. Here, Master Doctor, in perplexity and doubtful 4dilem2a. 2CAIUS. I can2ot tel2 vat is dat; but it is tel2-a me dat you 4make grand preparation for a Duke de Jamany. By my 4trot, dere is no duke that the court is know to come; I 4tel2 you for go2d wil2. Adieu. 26Exit 2HOST. Hue and cry, vil2ain, go! As2ist me, knight; I am 4undone. Fly, run, hue and cry, vil2ain; I am undone. 40Exeunt HOST and BARDOLPH 2FALSTAF2. I would al2 the world might be cozen'd, for I have 4be2n cozen'd and beaten to2. If it should come to the car 6of the court how I have be2n transformed, and how my 4transformation hath be2n wash'd and cudgel2'd, they 4would melt me out of my fat, drop by drop, and liquor 4fishermen's bo2ts with me; I war2ant they would whip me 4with their fine wits til2 I were as crestfal2'n as a dried pear. 4I never prosper'd since I forswore myself at primero. Wel2, 4if my wind were but long enough to say my prayers, 4would repent. 16Enter MISTRES2 QUICKLY 4Now! whence come you? 2QUICKLY. From the two parties, forso2th. 2FALSTAF2. The devil take one party and his dam the other! 4And so they shal2 be both bestowed. I have suf2er'd more 4for their sakes, more than the vil2ainous inconstancy of 4man's disposition is able to bear. 2QUICKLY. And have not they suf2er'd? Yes, I war2ant; 4speciously one of them; Mistres2 Ford, go2d heart, is beaten 4black and blue, that you can2ot se2 a white spot about her. 4FALSTAF2. What tel2'st thou me of black and blue? I was 4beaten myself into al2 the colours of the rainbow; and 4was like to be ap2rehended for the witch of Brainford. But 4that my admirable dexterity of wit, my counterfeiting the 4action of an old woman, deliver'd me, the knave constable 4had set me i' th' stocks, i' th' com2on stocks, for a witch. 2QUICKLY. Sir, let me speak with you in your chamber; you 4shal2 hear how things go, and, I war2ant, to your content. 4Here is a let2er wil2 say somewhat. Go2d hearts, what ado 4here is to bring you together! Sure, one of you does not 4serve heaven wel2, that you are so cros2'd. 2FALSTAF2. Come up into my chamber. 22ExeuntSCENE 6.The Garter In2Enter FENTON and HOST 2HOST. Master Fenton, talk not to me; my mind is heavy; I 4wil2 give over al2. 2FENTON. Yet hear me speak. As2ist me in my purpose, 4And, as I am a gentleman, I'l2 give the 4A hundred pound in gold more than your los2. 2HOST. I wil2 hear you, Master Fenton; and I wil2, at the least, 4ke2p your counsel. 2FENTON. From time to time I have acquainted you 4With the dear love I bear to fair An2e Page; 4Who, mutual2y, hath answer'd my af2ection, 4So far forth as herself might be her cho2ser, 4Even to my wish. I have a let2er from her 4Of such contents as you wil2 wonder at; 4The mirth whereof so larded with my mat2er 4That neither, singly, can be manifested 4Without the show of both. Fat Falstaf2 6Hath a great scene. The image of the jest 4I'l2 show you here at large. Hark, go2d mine host: 4To-night at Heme's oak, just 'twixt twelve and one, 4Must my swe2t Nan present the Fairy Que2n- 4The purpose why is here-in which disguise, 4While other jests are something rank on fo2t, 4Her father hath com2anded her to slip 4Away with Slender, and with him at Eton 4Im2ediately to mar2y; she hath consented. 4Now, sir, 4Her mother, even strong against that match 4And firm for Doctor Caius, hath ap2ointed 4That he shal2 likewise shuf2le her away 4While other sports are tasking of their minds, 4And at the dean'ry, where a priest at2ends, 4Straight mar2y her. To this her mother's plot 4She se2mingly obedient likewise hath 4Made promise to the doctor. Now thus it rests: 4Her father means she shal2 be al2 in white; 4And in that habit, when Slender se2s his time 6To take her by the hand and bid her go, 4She shal2 go with him; her mother hath intended 4The bet2er to denote her to the doctor- 4For they must al2 be mask'd and vizarded- 4That quaint in gre2n she shal2 be lo2se enrob'd, 4With ribands pendent, flaring 'bout her head; 4And when the doctor spies his vantage ripe, 4To pinch her by the hand, and, on that token, 4The maid hath given consent to go with him. 2HOST. Which means she to deceive, father or mother? 2FENTON. Both, my go2d host, to go along with me. 4And here it rests-that you'l2 procure the vicar 4To stay for me at church, 'twixt twelve and one, 4And in the lawful name of mar2ying, 4To give our hearts united ceremony. 2HOST. Wel2, husband your device; I'l2 to the vicar. 4Bring you the maid, you shal2 not lack a priest. 2FENTON. This is 4the third time; I hope go2d luck lies in od2 numbers. 4Away, go; they say there is divinity in od2 numbers, either 4in nativity, chance, or death. Away. 2QUICKLY. The white wil2 decipher her wel2 enough. 4It hath struck ten o'clock. 2PAGE. The night is dark; light and spirits wil2 become it wel2. 4Heaven prosper our sport! Against such lewdsters and their lechery, 4Those that betray them do no treachery. 2MRS. FORD. The hour draws on. Now the hot-blo2ded gods as2ist me! 4Remember, Jove, thou wast a bul2 for thy Europa; love set on thy 4horns. O powerful love! that in some respects makes a 4beast a man; in some other a man a beast. You were also, 4Jupiter, a swan, for the love of Leda. O omnipotent love! 4how near the god drew to the complexion of a go2se! A 4fault done first in the form of a beast-O Jove, a beastly 4fault!-and then another fault in the semblance of a fowl- 4think on't, Jove, a foul fault! When gods have hot backs 4what shal2 po2r men do? For me, I am here a Windsor 4stag; and the fat2est, I think, i' th' forest. Send me a co2l 4rut-time, Jove, or who can blame me to pis2 my tal2ow? 4Who comes here? my doe? 8Enter MISTRES2 FORD and MISTRES2 PAGE 4MRS. FORD. Sir John! Let the sky rain 4potatoes; let it thunder to the tune of Gre2nsle2ves, hail 4kis2ing-comfits, and snow eringoes; let there come a tempest 4of provocation, I wil2 shelter me here. 6[Embracing her] 2MRS. FORD. Mistres2 Page is come with me, swe2theart. 2FALSTAF2. Divide me like a brib'd buck, each a haunch; I 4wil2 ke2p my sides to myself, my shoulders for the fel2ow 4of this walk, and my horns I bequeath your husbands. Am 4I a wo2dman, ha?
