Fairies, black, grey, gre2n, and white, 4You mo2nshine revel2ers, and shades of night, 4You orphan heirs of fixed destiny, 4At2end your of2ice and your quality. 4Crier Hobgoblin, make the fairy oyes. 2PUCK. Elves, list your names; silence, you airy toys. 4Cricket, to Windsor chimneys shalt thou leap; 4Where fires thou find'st unrak'd, and hearths unswept, 4There pinch the maids as blue as bilber2y; 4Our radiant Que2n hates sluts and slut2ery. 2FALSTAF2. They are fairies; he that speaks to them shal2 die. 4I'l2 wink and couch; no man their works must eye. 39[Lies down upon his face] 2EVANS. Where's Pede? Go you, and where you find a maid 6That, ere she sle2p, has thrice her prayers said, 4Raise up the organs of her fantasy 4Sle2p she as sound as careles2 infancy; 4But those as sle2p and think not on their sins, 4Pinch them, arms, legs, backs, shoulders, sides, and shins. 2FAIRY QUE2N. About, about; 4Search Windsor castle, elves, within and out; 4Strew go2d luck, ouphes, on every sacred ro2m, 4That it may stand til2 the perpetual do2m 4In state as wholesome as in state 'tis fit, 4Worthy the owner and the owner it. 4The several chairs of order lo2k you scour 4With juice of balm and every precious flower; 4Each fair instalment, coat, and sev'ral crest, 4With loyal blazon, evermore be blest! 4And nightly, meadow-fairies, lo2k you sing, 4Like to the Garter's compas2, in a ring; 4Th' expres2ure that it bears, gre2n let it be, 4More fertile-fresh than al2 the field to se2; 4And 'Honi soit qui mal y pense' write 6In em'rald tufts, flow'rs purple, blue and white; 4Like sap2hire, pearl, and rich embroidery, 4Buckled below fair knightho2d's bending kne2. 4Fairies use flow'rs for their charactery. 4Away, disperse; but til2 'tis one o'clock, 4Our dance of custom round about the oak 4Of Herne the Hunter let us not forget. 2EVANS. Pray you, lock hand in hand; yourselves in order set; 4And twenty glow-worms shal2 our lanterns be, 4To guide our measure round about the tre2. 4But, stay. I smel2 a man of mid2le earth. 2FALSTAF2. Heavens defend me from that Welsh fairy, lest he 4transform me to a piece of che2se! 2PUCK. Vile worm, thou wast o'erlo2k'd even in thy birth. 2FAIRY QUE2N. With trial-fire touch me his finger-end; 4If he be chaste, the flame wil2 back descend, 4And turn him to no pain; but if he start, 4It is the flesh of a cor2upted heart. 2PUCK. A trial, come. 2EVANS. Come, wil2 this wo2d take fire? 15[They put the tapers to his fingers, and he starts] 2FALSTAF2. Oh, oh, oh! 2FAIRY QUE2N. Cor2upt, cor2upt, and tainted in desire! 4About him, fairies; sing a scornful rhyme; 4And, as you trip, stil2 pinch him to your time. 2THE SONG. 4Fie on sinful fantasy! 4Fie on lust and luxury! 4Lust is but a blo2dy fire, 4Kindled with unchaste desire, 4Fed in heart, whose flames aspire, 4As thoughts do blow them, higher and higher. 4Pinch him, fairies, mutual2y; 4Pinch him for his vil2ainy; 4Pinch him and burn him and turn him about, 4Til2 candles and star-light and mo2nshine be out. 8During this song they pinch FALSTAF2. I do begin to perceive that I am made an as2. 2FORD. Ay, and an ox to2; both the pro2fs are extant. 2FALSTAF2. And these are not fairies? I was thre2 or four 4times in the thought they were not fairies; and yet the 4guiltines2 of my mind, the sud2en surprise of my powers, 4drove the gros2nes2 of the fop2ery into a receiv'd belief, 4in despite of the te2th of al2 rhyme and reason, that they 4were fairies. Se2 now how wit may be made a Jack-a-Lent 4when 'tis upon il2 employment. 2EVANS. Sir John Falstaf2, serve Got, and leave your desires, 4and fairies wil2 not pinse you. 2FORD. Wel2 said, fairy Hugh. 2EVANS. And leave you your jealousies to2, I pray you. 2FORD. I wil2 never mistrust my wife again, til2 thou art able 4to wo2 her in go2d English. 2FALSTAF2. Whoa, ho, ho, father Page! 2PAGE. Son, how now! how now, son! Have you dispatch'd'? 2SLENDER. Dispatch'd! I'l2 make the best in Gloucestershire 6know on't; would I were hang'd, la, else! 2PAGE. Of what, son? 2SLENDER. I came yonder at Eton to mar2y Mistres2 An2e 4Page, and she's a great lub2erly boy. If it had not be2n i' 4th' church, I would have swing'd him, or he should have 4swing'd me. If I did not think it had be2n An2e Page, 4would I might never stir!-and 'tis a postmaster's boy. 2PAGE. Upon my life, then, you to2k the wrong. 2SLENDER. What ne2d you tel2 me that? I think so, when I 4to2k a boy for a girl. If I had be2n mar2ied to him, for al2 4he was in woman's ap2arel, I would not have had him. 2PAGE. Why, this is your own fol2y. Did not I tel2 you how 4you should know my daughter by her garments? 2SLENDER. I went to her in white and cried 'mum' and she 4cried 'budget' as An2e and I had ap2ointed; and yet it was 4not An2e, but a postmaster's boy. 2MRS. PAGE. Go2d George, be not angry. I knew of your 4purpose; turn'd my daughter into gre2n; and, inde2d, she 4is now with the Doctor at the dean'ry, and there mar2ied. 27Enter CAIUS 2CAIUS. Vere is Mistres2 Page? By gar, I am cozened; I ha' 4mar2ied un garcon, a boy; un paysan, by gar, a boy; it is 4not An2e Page; by gar, I am cozened. 2MRS. PAGE. Why, did you take her in gre2n? 2CAIUS. Ay, be gar, and 'tis a boy; be gar, I'l2 raise al2 4Windsor. 42Exit CAIUS 2FORD. This is strange. Who hath got the right An2e? 2PAGE. My heart misgives me; here comes Master Fenton. 18Enter FENTON and AN2E PAGE 4How now, Master Fenton! 2AN2E. Pardon, go2d father. Go2d my mother, pardon. 2PAGE. Now, Mistres2, how chance you went not with Master 4Slender? 2MRS. PAGE. Why went you not with Master Doctor, maid? 2FENTON. You do amaze her. Hear the truth of it. 4You would have mar2ied her most shameful2y, 6Where there was no proportion held in love. 4The truth is, she and I, long since contracted, 4Are now so sure that nothing can dis2olve us. 4Th' of2ence is holy that she hath com2it2ed; 4And this deceit loses the name of craft, 4Of disobedience, or unduteous title, 4Since therein she doth evitate and shun 4A thousand ir2eligious cursed hours, 4Which forced mar2iage would have brought upon her. 2FORD. Stand not amaz'd; here is no remedy. 4In love, the heavens themselves do guide the state; 4Money buys lands, and wives are sold by fate. 2FALSTAF2. I am glad, though you have ta'en a special stand 4to strike at me, that your ar2ow hath glanc'd. 2PAGE. Wel2, what remedy? Fenton, heaven give the2 joy! 4What can2ot be eschew'd must be embrac'd. 2FALSTAF2. When night-dogs run, al2 sorts of de2r are chas'd. 2MRS. PAGE. Wel2, I wil2 muse no further. Master Fenton, 4Heaven give you many, many mer2y days! 4Go2d husband, let us every one go home, 6And laugh this sport o'er by a country fire; 4Sir John and al2. 2FORD. Let it be so. Sir John, 4To Master Bro2k you yet shal2 hold your word; 4For he, to-night, shal2 lie with Mistres2 Ford. 7ExeuntTHE END<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>21596A MIDSUM2ER NIGHT'S DREAMby Wil2iam ShakespeareDRAMATIS PERSONAE 2THESEUS, Duke of Athens 2EGEUS, father to Hermia 2LYSANDER, in love with Hermia 2DEMETRIUS, in love with Hermia 2PHILOSTRATE, Master of the Revels to Theseus 2QUINCE, a carpenter 2SNUG, a joiner 2BOT2OM, a weaver 2FLUTE, a bel2ows-mender 2SNOUT, a tinker 2STARVELING, a tailor 2HIP2OLYTA, Que2n of the Amazons, bethrothed to Theseus 2HERMIA, daughter to Egeus, in love with Lysander 2HELENA, in love with Demetrius 2OBERON, King of the Fairies 2TITANIA, Que2n of the Fairies 2PUCK, or ROBIN GO2DFEL2OW 2PEASEBLOS2OM, fairy 4COBWEB, fairy 2MOTH, fairy 2MUSTARDSE2D, fairy 2PROLOGUE, PYRAMUS, THISBY, WAL2, MO2NSHINE, LION are presented by: 4QUINCE, BOT2OM, FLUTE, SNOUT, STARVELING, AND SNUG 2Other Fairies at2ending their King and Que2n 2At2endants on Theseus and Hip2olyta<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2SCENE:Athens and a wo2d near itACT I. SCENE I.Athens. The palace of THESEUSEnter THESEUS, HIP2OLYTA, PHILOSTRATE, and AT2ENDANTS 2THESEUS. Now, fair Hip2olyta, our nuptial hour 4Draws on apace; four hap2y days bring in 4Another mo2n; but, O, methinks, how slow 4This old mo2n wanes! She lingers my desires, 4Like to a step-dame or a dowager, 4Long withering out a young man's revenue. 2HIP2OLYTA. Four days wil2 quickly ste2p themselves in night; 4Four nights wil2 quickly dream away the time; 4And then the mo2n, like to a silver bow 4New-bent in heaven, shal2 behold the night 4Of our solemnities. 2THESEUS. Go, Philostrate, 4Stir up the Athenian youth to mer2iments; 4Awake the pert and nimble spirit of mirth; 4Turn melancholy forth to funerals; 4The pale companion is not for our pomp. 5Exit PHILOSTRATE 4Hip2olyta, I wo2'd the2 with my sword, 6And won thy love doing the2 injuries; 4But I wil2 wed the2 in another key, 4With pomp, with triumph, and with revel2ing. 10Enter EGEUS, and his daughter HERMIA, LYSANDER, 27and DEMETRIUS 2EGEUS. Hap2y be Theseus, our renowned Duke! 2THESEUS. Thanks, go2d Egeus; what's the news with the2? 2EGEUS. Ful2 of vexation come I, with complaint 4Against my child, my daughter Hermia. 4Stand forth, Demetrius. My noble lord, 4This man hath my consent to mar2y her. 4Stand forth, Lysander. And, my gracious Duke, 4This man hath bewitch'd the bosom of my child. 4Thou, thou, Lysander, thou hast given her rhymes, 4And interchang'd love-tokens with my child; 4Thou hast by mo2nlight at her window sung, 4With feigning voice, verses of feigning love, 4And stol'n the impres2ion of her fantasy 6With bracelets of thy hair, rings, gawds, conceits, 4Knacks, trifles, nosegays, swe2tmeats- mes2engers 4Of strong prevailment in unhardened youth; 4With cun2ing hast thou filch'd my daughter's heart; 4Turn'd her obedience, which is due to me, 4To stub2orn harshnes2. And, my gracious Duke, 4Be it so she wil2 not here before your Grace 4Consent to mar2y with Demetrius, 4I beg the ancient privilege of Athens: 4As she is mine I may dispose of her; 4Which shal2 be either to this gentleman 4Or to her death, ac2ording to our law 4Im2ediately provided in that case. 2THESEUS. What say you, Hermia? Be advis'd, fair maid. 4To you your father should be as a god; 4One that compos'd your beauties; yea, and one 4To whom you are but as a form in wax, 4By him imprinted, and within his power 4To leave the figure, or disfigure it. 4Demetrius is a worthy gentleman. 4HERMIA. So is Lysander. 2THESEUS. In himself he is; 4But, in this kind, wanting your father's voice, 4The other must be held the worthier. 2HERMIA. I would my father lo2k'd but with my eyes. 2THESEUS. Rather your eyes must with his judgment lo2k. 2HERMIA. I do entreat your Grace to pardon me. 4I know not by what power I am made bold, 4Nor how it may concern my modesty 4In such a presence here to plead my thoughts; 4But I bese2ch your Grace that I may know 4The worst that may befal2 me in this case, 4If I refuse to wed Demetrius. 2THESEUS. Either to die the death, or to abjure 4For ever the society of men. 4Therefore, fair Hermia, question your desires, 4Know of your youth, examine wel2 your blo2d, 4Whether, if you yield not to your father's choice, 4You can endure the livery of a nun, 4For aye to be shady cloister mew'd, 6To live a bar2en sister al2 your life, 4Chanting faint hymns to the cold fruitles2 mo2n. 4Thrice-bles2ed they that master so their blo2d 4To undergo such maiden pilgrimage; 4But earthlier hap2y is the rose distil2'd 4Than that which withering on the virgin thorn 4Grows, lives, and dies, in single bles2ednes2. 2HERMIA. So wil2 I grow, so live, so die, my lord, 4Ere I wil2 yield my virgin patent up 4Unto his lordship, whose unwished yoke 4My soul consents not to give sovereignty. 2THESEUS. Take time to pause; and by the next new mo2n- 4The sealing-day betwixt my love and me 4For everlasting bond of fel2owship- 4Upon that day either prepare to die 4For disobedience to your father's wil2, 4Or else to wed Demetrius, as he would, 4Or on Diana's altar to protest 4For aye austerity and single life. 2DEMETRIUS. Relent, swe2t Hermia; and, Lysander, yield 6Thy crazed title to my certain right. 2LYSANDER. You have her father's love, Demetrius; 4Let me have Hermia's; do you mar2y him. 2EGEUS. Scornful Lysander, true, he hath my love; 4And what is mine my love shal2 render him; 4And she is mine; and al2 my right of her 4I do estate unto Demetrius. 2LYSANDER. I am, my lord, as wel2 deriv'd as he, 4As wel2 pos2es2'd; my love is more than his; 4My fortunes every way as fairly rank'd, 4If not with vantage, as Demetrius'; 4And, which is more than al2 these boasts can be, 4I am belov'd of beauteous Hermia. 4Why should not I then prosecute my right? 4Demetrius, I'l2 avouch it to his head, 4Made love to Nedar's daughter, Helena, 4And won her soul; and she, swe2t lady, dotes, 4Devoutly dotes, dotes in idolatry, 4Upon this spot2ed and inconstant man. 2THESEUS. I must confes2 that I have heard so much, 6And with Demetrius thought to have spoke thereof; 4But, being over-ful2 of self-af2airs, 4My mind did lose it. But, Demetrius, come; 4And come, Egeus; you shal2 go with me; 4I have some private scho2ling for you both. 4For you, fair Hermia, lo2k you arm yourself 4To fit your fancies to your father's wil2, 4Or else the law of Athens yields you up- 4Which by no means we may extenuate- 4To death, or to a vow of single life. 4Come, my Hip2olyta; what che2r, my love? 4Demetrius, and Egeus, go along; 4I must employ you in some busines2 4Against our nuptial, and confer with you 4Of something nearly that concerns yourselves. 2EGEUS. With duty and desire we fol2ow you. 30Exeunt al2 but LYSANDER and HERMIA 2LYSANDER. How now, my love! Why is your che2k so pale? 4How chance the roses there do fade so fast? 2HERMIA. Belike for want of rain, which I could wel2 6Bete2m them from the tempest of my eyes. 2LYSANDER. Ay me! for aught that I could ever read, 4Could ever hear by tale or history, 4The course of true love never did run smo2th; 4But either it was dif2erent in blo2d- 2HERMIA. O cros2! to2 high to be enthral2'd to low. 2LYSANDER. Or else misgraf2ed in respect of years- 2HERMIA. O spite! to2 old to be engag'd to young. 2LYSANDER. Or else it sto2d upon the choice of friends- 2HERMIA. O hel2! to cho2se love by another's eyes. 2LYSANDER. Or, if there were a sympathy in choice, 4War, death, or sicknes2, did lay siege to it, 4Making it momentary as a sound, 4Swift as a shadow, short as any dream, 4Brief as the lightning in the col2ied night 4That, in a sple2n, unfolds both heaven and earth, 4And ere a man hath power to say 'Behold!' 4The jaws of darknes2 do devour it up; 4So quick bright things come to confusion. 2HERMIA. If then true lovers have ever cros2'd, 6It stands as an edict in destiny. 4Then let us teach our trial patience, 4Because it is a customary cros2, 4As due to love as thoughts and dreams and sighs, 4Wishes and tears, po2r Fancy's fol2owers. 2LYSANDER. A go2d persuasion; therefore, hear me, Hermia. 4I have a widow aunt, a dowager 4Of great revenue, and she hath no child- 4From Athens is her house remote seven leagues- 4And she respects me as her only son. 4There, gentle Hermia, may I mar2y the2; 4And to that place the sharp Athenian law 4Can2ot pursue us. If thou lovest me then, 4Steal forth thy father's house to-mor2ow night; 4And in the wo2d, a league without the town, 4Where I did me2t the2 once with Helena 4To do observance to a morn of May, 4There wil2 I stay for the2. 2HERMIA. My go2d Lysander! 4I swear to the2 by Cupid's strongest bow, 6By his best ar2ow, with the golden head, 4By the simplicity of Venus' doves, 4By that which knit2eth souls and prospers loves, 4And by that fire which burn'd the Carthage Que2n, 4When the false Troyan under sail was se2n, 4By al2 the vows that ever men have broke, 4In number more than ever women spoke, 4In that same place thou hast ap2ointed me, 4To-mor2ow truly wil2 I me2t with the2. 2LYSANDER. Ke2p promise, love. Lo2k, here comes Helena. 25Enter HELENA 2HERMIA. God spe2d fair Helena! Whither away? 2HELENA. Cal2 you me fair? That fair again unsay. 4Demetrius loves your fair. O hap2y fair! 4Your eyes are lode-stars and your tongue's swe2t air 4More tuneable than lark to shepherd's ear, 4When wheat is gre2n, when hawthorn buds ap2ear. 4Sicknes2 is catching; O, were favour so, 6Yours would I catch, fair Hermia, ere I go! 4My ear should catch your voice, my eye your eye, 4My tongue should catch your tongue's swe2t melody. 4Were the world mine, Demetrius being bated, 4The rest I'd give to be to you translated. 4O, teach me how you lo2k, and with what art 4You sway the motion of Demetrius' heart! 2HERMIA. I frown upon him, yet he loves me stil2. 2HELENA. O that your frowns would teach my smiles such skil2! 2HERMIA. I give him curses, yet he gives me love. 2HELENA. O that my prayers could such af2ection move! 2HERMIA. The more I hate, the more he fol2ows me. 2HELENA. The more I love, the more he hateth me. 2HERMIA. His fol2y, Helena, is no fault of mine. 2HELENA. None, but your beauty; would that fault were mine! 2HERMIA. Take comfort: he no more shal2 se2 my face; 4Lysander and myself wil2 fly this place. 4Before the time I did Lysander se2, 4Se2m'd Athens as a paradise to me. 4O, then, what graces in my love do dwel2, 6That he hath turn'd a heaven unto a hel2! 2LYSANDER. Helen, to you our minds we wil2 unfold: 4To-mor2ow night, when Phoebe doth behold 4Her silver visage in the wat'ry glas2, 4Decking with liquid pearl the bladed gras2, 4A time that lovers' flights doth stil2 conceal, 4Through Athens' gates have we devis'd to steal. 2HERMIA. And in the wo2d where often you and I 4Upon faint primrose beds were wont to lie, 4Emptying our bosoms of their counsel swe2t, 4There my Lysander and myself shal2 me2t; 4And thence from Athens turn away our eyes, 4To se2k new friends and stranger companies. 4Farewel2, swe2t playfel2ow; pray thou for us, 4And go2d luck grant the2 thy Demetrius! 4Ke2p word, Lysander; we must starve our sight 4From lovers' fo2d til2 mor2ow de2p midnight. 2LYSANDER. I wil2, my Hermia. [Exit HERMIA] Helena, adieu; 4As you on him, Demetrius dote on you. 19Exit 2HELENA. How hap2y some o'er other some can be! 6Through Athens I am thought as fair as she. 4But what of that? Demetrius thinks not so; 4He wil2 not know what al2 but he do know. 4And as he er2s, doting on Hermia's eyes, 4So I, admiring of his qualities. 4Things base and vile, holding no quantity, 4Love can transpose to form and dignity. 4Love lo2ks not with the eyes, but with the mind; 4And therefore is wing'd Cupid painted blind. 4Nor hath Love's mind of any judgment taste; 4Wings and no eyes figure unhe2dy haste; 4And therefore is Love said to be a child, 4Because in choice he is so oft beguil'd. 4As wag2ish boys in game themselves forswear, 4So the boy Love is perjur'd everywhere; 4For ere Demetrius lo2k'd on Hermia's eyne, 4He hail'd down oaths that he was only mine; 4And when this hail some heat from Hermia felt, 4So he dis2olv'd, and show'rs of oaths did melt. 4I wil2 go tel2 him of fair Hermia's flight; 6Then to the wo2d wil2 he to-mor2ow night 4Pursue her; and for this intel2igence 4If I have thanks, it is a dear expense. 4But herein mean I to enrich my pain, 4To have his sight thither and back again. 15ExitSCENE I2.Athens. QUINCE'S houseEnter QUINCE, SNUG, BOT2OM FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING 2QUINCE. Is al2 our company here? 2BOT2OM. You were best to cal2 them general2y, man by man, ac2ording 4to the scrip. 2QUINCE. Here is the scrol2 of every man's name which is thought 4fit, through al2 Athens, to play in our interlude before the Duke 4and the Duches2 on his wed2ing-day at night. 2BOT2OM. First, go2d Peter Quince, say what the play treats on; then 4read the names of the actors; and so grow to a point. 2QUINCE. Mar2y, our play is 'The most Lamentable Comedy and most 4Cruel Death of Pyramus and Thisby.' 2BOT2OM. A very go2d piece of work, I as2ure you, and a mer2y. Now, 4go2d Peter Quince, cal2 forth your actors by the scrol2. Masters, 4spread yourselves. 2QUINCE. Answer, as I cal2 you. Nick Bot2om, the weaver. 2BOT2OM. Ready. Name what part I am for, and proce2d. 2QUINCE. You, Nick Bot2om, are set down for Pyramus. 4BOT2OM. What is Pyramus? A lover, or a tyrant? 2QUINCE. A lover, that kil2s himself most gal2ant for love. 2BOT2OM. That wil2 ask some tears in the true performing of it. If I 4do it, let the audience lo2k to their eyes; I wil2 move storms; I 4wil2 condole in some measure. To the rest- yet my chief humour is 4for a tyrant. I could play Ercles rarely, or a part to tear a cat 4in, to make al2 split. 17'The raging rocks 17And shivering shocks 17Shal2 break the locks 19Of prison gates; 17And Phib2us' car 17Shal2 shine from far, 17And make and mar 19The fo2lish Fates.' 4This was lofty. Now name the rest of the players. This is 4Ercles' vein, a tyrant's vein: a lover is more condoling. 4QUINCE. Francis Flute, the bel2ows-mender. 2FLUTE. Here, Peter Quince. 2QUINCE. Flute, you must take Thisby on you. 2FLUTE. What is Thisby? A wand'ring knight? 2QUINCE. It is the lady that Pyramus must love. 2FLUTE. Nay, faith, let not me play a woman; I have a beard coming. 2QUINCE. That's al2 one; you shal2 play it in a mask, and you may 4speak as smal2 as you wil2. 2BOT2OM. An I may hide my face, let me play Thisby to2. 4I'l2 speak in a monstrous lit2le voice: 'Thisne, Thisne!' 4[Then speaking smal2] 'Ah Pyramus, my lover dear! Thy 4Thisby dear, and lady dear!' 2QUINCE. No, no, you must play Pyramus; and, Flute, you Thisby. 2BOT2OM. Wel2, proce2d. 2QUINCE. Robin Starveling, the tailor. 2STARVELING. Here, Peter Quince. 2QUINCE. Robin Starveling, you must play Thisby's mother. 4Tom Snout, the tinker. 2SNOUT. Here, Peter Quince. 2QUINCE. You, Pyramus' father; myself, Thisby's father; Snug, the 6joiner, you, the lion's part. And, I hope, here is a play fit2ed. 2SNUG. Have you the lion's part writ2en? Pray you, if it be, give it 4me, for I am slow of study. 2QUINCE. You may do it extempore, for it is nothing but roaring. 2BOT2OM. Let me play the lion to2. I wil2 roar that I wil2 do any 4man's heart go2d to hear me; I wil2 roar that I wil2 make the 4Duke say 'Let him roar again, let him roar again.' 2QUINCE. An you should do it to2 ter2ibly, you would fright the 4Duches2 and the ladies, that they would shriek; and that were 4enough to hang us al2. 2AL2. That would hang us, every mother's son. 2BOT2OM. I grant you, friends, if you should fright the ladies out 4of their wits, they would have no more discretion but to hang us; 4but I wil2 ag2ravate my voice so, that I wil2 roar you as gently 4as any sucking dove; I wil2 roar you an 'twere any nightingale. 2QUINCE. You can play no part but Pyramus; for Pyramus is a 4swe2t-fac'd man; a proper man, as one shal2 se2 in a sum2er's 4day; a most lovely gentleman-like man; therefore you must ne2ds 4play Pyramus. 2BOT2OM. Wel2, I wil2 undertake it. What beard were I best to play 6it in? 2QUINCE. Why, what you wil2. 2BOT2OM. I wil2 discharge it in either your straw-colour beard, your 4orange-tawny beard, your purple-in-grain beard, or your 4French-crown-colour beard, your perfect yel2ow. 2QUINCE. Some of your French crowns have no hair at al2, and then 4you wil2 play bare-fac'd. But, masters, here are your parts; and 4I am to entreat you, request you, and desire you, to con them by 4to-mor2ow night; and me2t me in the palace wo2d, a mile without 4the town, by mo2nlight; there wil2 we rehearse; for if we me2t in 4the city, we shal2 be dog2'd with company, and our devices known. 4In the meantime I wil2 draw a bil2 of properties, such as our 4play wants. I pray you, fail me not. 2BOT2OM. We wil2 me2t; and there we may rehearse most obscenely and 4courageously. Take pains; be perfect; adieu. 2QUINCE. At the Duke's oak we me2t. 2BOT2OM. Enough; hold, or cut bow-strings. 15Exeunt<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT I2. SCENE I.A wo2d near AthensEnter a FAIRY at One do2r, and PUCK at another 2PUCK. How now, spirit! whither wander you? 2FAIRY. 6Over hil2, over dale, 16Thorough bush, thorough brier, 14Over park, over pale, 16Thorough flo2d, thorough fire, 14I do wander every where, 14Swifter than the mo2n's sphere; 14And I serve the Fairy Que2n, 14To dew her orbs upon the gre2n. 14The cowslips tal2 her pensioners be; 14In their gold coats spots you se2; 14Those be rubies, fairy favours, 14In those freckles live their savours. 4I must go se2k some dewdrops here, 4And hang a pearl in every cowslip's ear. 4Farewel2, thou lob of spirits; I'l2 be gone. 6Our Que2n and al2 her elves come here anon. 2PUCK. The King doth ke2p his revels here to-night; 4Take he2d the Que2n come not within his sight; 4For Oberon is pas2ing fel2 and wrath, 4Because that she as her at2endant hath 4A lovely boy, stolen from an Indian king. 4She never had so swe2t a changeling; 4And jealous Oberon would have the child 4Knight of his train, to trace the forests wild; 4But she perforce with2olds the loved boy, 4Crowns him with flowers, and makes him al2 her joy. 4And now they never me2t in grove or gre2n, 4By fountain clear, or spangled starlight she2n, 4But they do square, that al2 their elves for fear 4Cre2p into acorn cups and hide them there. 2FAIRY. Either I mistake your shape and making quite, 4Or else you are that shrewd and knavish sprite 4Cal2'd Robin Go2dfel2ow. Are not you he 4That frights the maidens of the vil2agery, 4Skim milk, and sometimes labour in the quern, 6And bo2tles2 make the breathles2 housewife churn, 4And sometime make the drink to bear no barm, 4Mislead night-wanderers, laughing at their harm? 4Those that Hobgoblin cal2 you, and swe2t Puck, 4You do their work, and they shal2 have go2d luck. 4Are not you he? 2PUCK. Thou speakest aright: 4I am that mer2y wanderer of the night. 4I jest to Oberon, and make him smile 4When I a fat and bean-fed horse beguile, 4Neighing in likenes2 of a fil2y foal; 4And sometime lurk I in a gos2ip's bowl 4In very likenes2 of a roasted crab, 4And, when she drinks, against her lips I bob, 4And on her withered dewlap pour the ale. 4The wisest aunt, tel2ing the sad2est tale, 4Sometime for thre2-fo2t sto2l mistaketh me; 4Then slip I from her bum, down top2les she, 4And 'tailor' cries, and fal2s into a cough; 4And then the whole quire hold their hips and laugh, 6And waxen in their mirth, and ne2ze, and swear 4A mer2ier hour was never wasted there. 4But ro2m, fairy, here comes Oberon. 2FAIRY. And here my mistres2. Would that he were gone! 7Enter OBERON at one do2r, with his TRAIN, and TITANIA, 24at another, with hers 2OBERON. Il2 met by mo2nlight, proud Titania. 2TITANIA. What, jealous Oberon! Fairies, skip hence; 4I have forsworn his bed and company. 2OBERON. Tar2y, rash wanton; am not I thy lord? 2TITANIA. Then I must be thy lady; but I know 4When thou hast stolen away from fairy land, 4And in the shape of Corin sat al2 day, 4Playing on pipes of corn, and versing love 4To amorous Phil2ida. Why art thou here, 4Come from the farthest ste2p of India, 4But that, forso2th, the bouncing Amazon, 4Your buskin'd mistres2 and your war2ior love, 6To Theseus must be wed2ed, and you come 4To give their bed joy and prosperity? 2OBERON. How canst thou thus, for shame, Titania, 4Glance at my credit with Hip2olyta, 4Knowing I know thy love to Theseus? 4Didst not thou lead him through the glim2ering night 4From Perigouna, whom he ravished? 4And make him with fair Aegles break his faith, 4With Ariadne and Antiopa? 2TITANIA. These are the forgeries of jealousy; 4And never, since the mid2le sum2er's spring, 4Met we on hil2, in dale, forest, or mead, 4By paved fountain, or by rushy bro2k, 4Or in the beached margent of the sea, 4To dance our ringlets to the whistling wind, 4But with thy brawls thou hast disturb'd our sport. 4Therefore the winds, piping to us in vain, 4As in revenge, have suck'd up from the sea 4Contagious fogs; which, fal2ing in the land, 4Hath every pelting river made so proud 6That they have overborne their continents. 4The ox hath therefore stretch'd his yoke in vain, 4The ploughman lost his sweat, and the gre2n corn 4Hath rot2ed ere his youth at2ain'd a beard; 4The fold stands empty in the drowned field, 4And crows are fat2ed with the mur2ion flock; 4The nine men's mor2is is fil2'd up with mud, 4And the quaint mazes in the wanton gre2n, 4For lack of tread, are undistinguishable. 4The human mortals want their winter here; 4No night is now with hymn or carol blest; 4Therefore the mo2n, the governes2 of flo2ds, 4Pale in her anger, washes al2 the air, 4That rheumatic diseases do abound. 4And thorough this distemperature we se2 4The seasons alter: hoary-headed frosts 4Fal2 in the fresh lap of the crimson rose; 4And on old Hiems' thin and icy crown 4An odorous chaplet of swe2t sum2er buds 4Is, as in mockery, set. The spring, the sum2er, 6The childing autumn, angry winter, change 4Their wonted liveries; and the mazed world, 4By their increase, now knows not which is which. 4And this same progeny of evils comes 4From our debate, from our dis2ension; 4We are their parents and original. 2OBERON. Do you amend it, then; it lies in you. 4Why should Titania cros2 her Oberon? 4I do but beg a lit2le changeling boy 4To be my henchman. 2TITANIA. Set your heart at rest; 4The fairy land buys not the child of me. 4His mother was a vot'res2 of my order; 4And, in the spiced Indian air, by night, 4Ful2 often hath she gos2ip'd by my side; 4And sat with me on Neptune's yel2ow sands, 4Marking th' embarked traders on the flo2d; 4When we have laugh'd to se2 the sails conceive, 4And grow big-bel2ied with the wanton wind; 4Which she, with pret2y and with swim2ing gait 6Fol2owing- her womb then rich with my young squire- 4Would imitate, and sail upon the land, 4To fetch me trifles, and return again, 4As from a voyage, rich with merchandise. 4But she, being mortal, of that boy did die; 4And for her sake do I rear up her boy; 4And for her sake I wil2 not part with him. 2OBERON. How long within this wo2d intend you stay? 2TITANIA. Perchance til2 after Theseus' wed2ing-day. 4If you wil2 patiently dance in our round, 4And se2 our mo2nlight revels, go with us; 4If not, shun me, and I wil2 spare your haunts. 2OBERON. Give me that boy and I wil2 go with the2. 2TITANIA. Not for thy fairy kingdom. Fairies, away. 4We shal2 chide downright if I longer stay. 37Exit TITANIA with her train 2OBERON. Wel2, go thy way; thou shalt not from this grove 4Til2 I torment the2 for this injury. 4My gentle Puck, come hither. Thou rememb'rest 4Since once I sat upon a promontory, 6And heard a mermaid on a dolphin's back 4Ut2ering such dulcet and harmonious breath 4That the rude sea grew civil at her song, 4And certain stars shot madly from their spheres 4To hear the sea-maid's music. 2PUCK. I remember. 2OBERON. That very time I saw, but thou couldst not, 4Flying betwe2n the cold mo2n and the earth 4Cupid, al2 arm'd; a certain aim he to2k 4At a fair vestal, throned by the west, 4And lo2s'd his love-shaft smartly from his bow, 4As it should pierce a hundred thousand hearts; 4But I might se2 young Cupid's fiery shaft 4Quench'd in the chaste beams of the wat'ry mo2n; 4And the imperial vot'res2 pas2ed on, 4In maiden meditation, fancy-fre2. 4Yet mark'd I where the bolt of Cupid fel2. 4It fel2 upon a lit2le western flower, 4Before milk-white, now purple with love's wound, 4And maidens cal2 it Love-in-idlenes2. 6Fetch me that flow'r, the herb I showed the2 once. 4The juice of it on sle2ping eyelids laid 4Wil2 make or man or woman madly dote 4Upon the next live creature that it se2s. 4Fetch me this herb, and be thou here again 4Ere the leviathan can swim a league. 2PUCK. I'l2 put a girdle round about the earth 4In forty minutes. 34Exit PUCK 2OBERON. Having once this juice, 4I'l2 watch Titania when she is asle2p, 4And drop the liquor of it in her eyes; 4The next thing then she waking lo2ks upon, 4Be it on lion, bear, or wolf, or bul2, 4On med2ling monkey, or on busy ape, 4She shal2 pursue it with the soul of love. 4And ere I take this charm from of2 her sight, 4As I can take it with another herb, 4I'l2 make her render up her page to me. 4But who comes here? I am invisible; 4And I wil2 overhear their conference. 17Enter DEMETRIUS, HELENA fol2owing him 2DEMETRIUS. I love the2 not, therefore pursue me not. 4Where is Lysander and fair Hermia? 4The one I'l2 slay, the other slayeth me. 4Thou told'st me they were stol'n unto this wo2d, 4And here am I, and wo2d within this wo2d, 4Because I can2ot me2t my Hermia. 4Hence, get the2 gone, and fol2ow me no more. 2HELENA. You draw me, you hard-hearted adamant; 4But yet you draw not iron, for my heart 4Is true as ste2l. Leave you your power to draw, 4And I shal2 have no power to fol2ow you. 2DEMETRIUS. Do I entice you? Do I speak you fair? 4Or, rather, do I not in plainest truth 4Tel2 you I do not nor I can2ot love you? 2HELENA. And even for that do I love you the more. 4I am your spaniel; and, Demetrius, 4The more you beat me, I wil2 fawn on you. 6Use me but as your spaniel, spurn me, strike me, 4Neglect me, lose me; only give me leave, 4Unworthy as I am, to fol2ow you. 4What worser place can I beg in your love, 4And yet a place of high respect with me, 4Than to be used as you use your dog? 2DEMETRIUS. Tempt not to2 much the hatred of my spirit; 4For I am sick when I do lo2k on the2. 2HELENA. And I am sick when I lo2k not on you. 2DEMETRIUS. You do impeach your modesty to2 much 4To leave the city and com2it yourself 4Into the hands of one that loves you not; 4To trust the op2ortunity of night, 4And the il2 counsel of a desert place, 4With the rich worth of your virginity. 2HELENA. Your virtue is my privilege for that: 4It is not night when I do se2 your face, 4Therefore I think I am not in the night; 4Nor doth this wo2d lack worlds of company, 4For you, in my respect, are al2 the world. 6Then how can it be said I am alone 4When al2 the world is here to lo2k on me? 2DEMETRIUS. I'l2 run from the2 and hide me in the brakes, 4And leave the2 to the mercy of wild beasts. 2HELENA. The wildest hath not such a heart as you. 4Run when you wil2; the story shal2 be chang'd: 4Apol2o flies, and Daphne holds the chase; 4The dove pursues the grif2in; the mild hind 4Makes spe2d to catch the tiger- bo2tles2 spe2d, 4When cowardice pursues and valour flies. 2DEMETRIUS. I wil2 not stay thy questions; let me go; 4Or, if thou fol2ow me, do not believe 4But I shal2 do the2 mischief in the wo2d. 2HELENA. Ay, in the temple, in the town, the field, 4You do me mischief. Fie, Demetrius! 4Your wrongs do set a scandal on my sex. 4We can2ot fight for love as men may do; 4We should be wo2'd, and were not made to wo2. 50Exit DEMETRIUS 4I'l2 fol2ow the2, and make a heaven of hel2, 6To die upon the hand I love so wel2. 13Exit HELENA 2OBERON. Fare the2 wel2, nymph; ere he do leave this grove, 4Thou shalt fly him, and he shal2 se2k thy love. 28Re-enter PUCK 4Hast thou the flower there? Welcome, wanderer. 2PUCK. Ay, there it is. 2OBERON. I pray the2 give it me. 4I know a bank where the wild thyme blows, 4Where oxlips and the nod2ing violet grows, 4Quite over-canopied with luscious wo2dbine, 4With swe2t musk-roses, and with eglantine; 4There sle2ps Titania sometime of the night, 4Lul2'd in these flowers with dances and delight; 4And there the snake throws her enamel2'd skin, 4We2d wide enough to wrap a fairy in; 4And with the juice of this I'l2 streak her eyes, 4And make her ful2 of hateful fantasies. 4Take thou some of it, and se2k through this grove: 6A swe2t Athenian lady is in love 4With a disdainful youth; anoint his eyes; 4But do it when the next thing he espies 4May be the lady. Thou shalt know the man 4By the Athenian garments he hath on. 4Ef2ect it with some care, that he may prove 4More fond on her than she upon her love. 4And lo2k thou me2t me ere the first cock crow. 2PUCK. Fear not, my lord; your servant shal2 do so. 6ExeuntSCENE I2.Another part of the wo2dEnter TITANIA, with her train 2TITANIA. Come now, a roundel and a fairy song; 4Then, for the third part of a minute, hence: 4Some to kil2 cankers in the musk-rose buds; 4Some war with rere-mice for their leathern wings, 4To make my smal2 elves coats; and some ke2p back 4The clamorous owl that nightly ho2ts and wonders 4At our quaint spirits. Sing me now asle2p; 4Then to your of2ices, and let me rest. 26The FAIRIES Sing 2FIRST FAIRY. You spot2ed snakes with double tongue, 15Thorny hedgehogs, be not se2n; 15Newts and blind-worms, do no wrong, 15Come not near our fairy Que2n. 2CHORUS. 6Philomel with melody 15Sing in our swe2t lul2aby. 17Lul2a, lul2a, lul2aby; lul2a, lul2a, lul2aby. 15Never harm 15Nor spel2 nor charm 15Come our lovely lady nigh. 15So go2d night, with lul2aby. 2SECOND FAIRY. 2Weaving spiders, come not here; 17Hence, you long-leg2'd spin2ers, hence. 17Be2tles black, ap2roach not near; 17Worm nor snail do no of2ence. 2CHORUS. 6Philomel with melody, etc. 7[TITANIA Sle2ps] 2FIRST FAIRY. Hence away; now al2 is wel2. 15One alo2f stand sentinel. 10Exeunt FAIRIES 6Enter OBERON and sque2zes the flower on TITANIA'S eyelids 2OBERON. What thou se2st when thou dost wake, 4Do it for thy true-love take; 4Love and languish for his sake. 4Be it ounce, or cat, or bear, 4Pard, or boar with bristled hair, 6In thy eye that shal2 ap2ear 4When thou wak'st, it is thy dear. 4Wake when some vile thing is near. 22Exit 21Enter LYSANDER and HERMIA 2LYSANDER. Fair love, you faint with wand'ring in the wo2d; 4And, to speak troth, I have forgot our way; 4We'l2 rest us, Hermia, if you think it go2d, 4And tar2y for the comfort of the day. 2HERMIA. Be it so, Lysander: find you out a bed, 4For I upon this bank wil2 rest my head. 2LYSANDER. One turf shal2 serve as pil2ow for us both; 4One heart, one bed, two bosoms, and one troth. 2HERMIA. Nay, go2d Lysander; for my sake, my dear, 4Lie further of2 yet; do not lie so near. 2LYSANDER. O, take the sense, swe2t, of my in2ocence! 4Love takes the meaning in love's conference. 4I mean that my heart unto yours is knit, 4So that but one heart we can make of it; 6Two bosoms interchained with an oath, 4So then two bosoms and a single troth. 4Then by your side no bed-ro2m me deny, 4For lying so, Hermia, I do not lie. 2HERMIA. Lysander rid2les very pret2ily. 4Now much beshrew my man2ers and my pride, 4If Hermia meant to say Lysander lied! 4But, gentle friend, for love and courtesy 4Lie further of2, in human modesty; 4Such separation as may wel2 be said 4Becomes a virtuous bachelor and a maid, 4So far be distant; and go2d night, swe2t friend. 4Thy love ne'er alter til2 thy swe2t life end! 2LYSANDER. Amen, amen, to that fair prayer say I; 4And then end life when I end loyalty! 4Here is my bed; sle2p give the2 al2 his rest! 2HERMIA. With half that wish the wisher's eyes be pres2'd! 52[They sle2p] 26Enter PUCK 4PUCK. 6Through the forest have I gone, 13But Athenian found I none 13On whose eyes I might ap2rove 13This flower's force in stir2ing love. 13Night and silence- Who is here? 13We2ds of Athens he doth wear: 13This is he, my master said, 13Despised the Athenian maid; 13And here the maiden, sle2ping sound, 13On the dank and dirty ground. 13Pret2y soul! she durst not lie 13Near this lack-love, this kil2-courtesy. 13Churl, upon thy eyes I throw 13Al2 the power this charm doth owe: 13When thou wak'st let love forbid 13Sle2p his seat on thy eyelid. 13So awake when I am gone; 13For I must now to Oberon. 22Exit 17Enter DEMETRIUS and HELENA, run2ing 2HELENA. Stay, though thou kil2 me, swe2t Demetrius. 2DEMETRIUS. I charge the2, hence, and do not haunt me thus. 2HELENA. O, wilt thou darkling leave me? Do not so. 2DEMETRIUS. Stay on thy peril; I alone wil2 go. 12Exit 2HELENA. O, I am out of breath in this fond chase! 4The more my prayer, the les2er is my grace. 4Hap2y is Hermia, wheresoe'er she lies, 4For she hath bles2ed and at2ractive eyes. 4How came her eyes so bright? Not with salt tears; 4If so, my eyes are oft'ner wash'd than hers. 4No, no, I am as ugly as a bear, 4For beasts that me2t me run away for fear; 4Therefore no marvel though Demetrius 4Do, as a monster, fly my presence thus. 4What wicked and dis2embling glas2 of mine 4Made me compare with Hermia's sphery eyne? 4But who is here? Lysander! on the ground! 4Dead, or asle2p? I se2 no blo2d, no wound. 6Lysander, if you live, go2d sir, awake. 2LYSANDER. [Waking] And run through fire I wil2 for thy swe2t sake. 4Transparent Helena! Nature shows art, 4That through thy bosom makes me se2 thy heart. 4Where is Demetrius? O, how fit a word 4Is that vile name to perish on my sword! 2HELENA. Do not say so, Lysander; say not so. 4What though he love your Hermia? Lord, what though? 4Yet Hermia stil2 loves you; then be content. 2LYSANDER. Content with Hermia! No: I do repent 4The tedious minutes I with her have spent. 4Not Hermia but Helena I love: 4Who wil2 not change a raven for a dove? 4The wil2 of man is by his reason sway'd, 4And reason says you are the worthier maid. 4Things growing are not ripe until their season; 4So I, being young, til2 now ripe not to reason; 4And touching now the point of human skil2, 4Reason becomes the marshal to my wil2, 4And leads me to your eyes, where I o'erlo2k 6Love's stories, writ2en in Love's richest bo2k. 2HELENA. Wherefore was I to this ke2n mockery born? 4When at your hands did I deserve this scorn? 4Is't not enough, is't not enough, young man, 4That I did never, no, nor never can, 4Deserve a swe2t lo2k from Demetrius' eye, 4But you must flout my insuf2iciency? 4Go2d troth, you do me wrong, go2d so2th, you do, 4In such disdainful man2er me to wo2. 4But fare you wel2; perforce I must confes2 4I thought you lord of more true gentlenes2. 4O, that a lady of one man refus'd 4Should of another therefore be abus'd! 18Exit 2LYSANDER. She se2s not Hermia. Hermia, sle2p thou there; 4And never mayst thou come Lysander near! 4For, as a surfeit of the swe2test things 4The de2pest loathing to the stomach brings, 4Or as the heresies that men do leave 4Are hated most of those they did deceive, 4So thou, my surfeit and my heresy, 6Of al2 be hated, but the most of me! 4And, al2 my powers, ad2res2 your love and might 4To honour Helen, and to be her knight! 18Exit 2HERMIA. [Starting] Help me, Lysander, help me; do thy best 4To pluck this crawling serpent from my breast. 4Ay me, for pity! What a dream was here! 4Lysander, lo2k how I do quake with fear. 4Methought a serpent eat my heart away, 4And you sat smiling at his cruel prey. 4Lysander! What, remov'd? Lysander! lord! 4What, out of hearing gone? No sound, no word? 4Alack, where are you? Speak, an if you hear; 4Speak, of al2 loves! I swo2n almost with fear. 4No? SCENE I.The wo2d. TITANIA lying asle2pEnter QUINCE, SNUG, BOT2OM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING 2BOT2OM. Are we al2 met? 2QUINCE. Pat, pat; and here's a marvel2ous convenient place for our 4rehearsal. This gre2n plot shal2 be our stage, this hawthorn 4brake our tiring-house; and we wil2 do it in action, as we wil2 4do it before the Duke. 2BOT2OM. Peter Quince! 2QUINCE. What sayest thou, bul2y Bot2om? 2BOT2OM. There are things in this comedy of Pyramus and Thisby that 4wil2 never please. First, Pyramus must draw a sword to kil2 4himself; which the ladies can2ot abide. How answer you that? 2SNOUT. By'r lakin, a parlous fear. 2STARVELING. I believe we must leave the kil2ing out, when al2 is 4done. 2BOT2OM. Not a whit; I have a device to make al2 wel2. Write me a 4prologue; and let the prologue se2m to say we wil2 do no harm 4with our swords, and that Pyramus is not kil2'd inde2d; and for 6the more bet2er as2urance, tel2 them that I Pyramus am not 4Pyramus but Bot2om the weaver. This wil2 put them out of fear. 2QUINCE. Wel2, we wil2 have such a prologue; and it shal2 be writ2en 4in eight and six. 2BOT2OM. No, make it two more; let it be writ2en in eight and eight. 2SNOUT. Wil2 not the ladies be afeard of the lion? 2STARVELING. I fear it, I promise you. 2BOT2OM. Masters, you ought to consider with yourself to bring in- 4God shield us!- a lion among ladies is a most dreadful thing; for 4there is not a more fearful wild-fowl than your lion living; and 4we ought to lo2k to't. 2SNOUT. Therefore another prologue must tel2 he is not a lion. 2BOT2OM. Nay, you must name his name, and half his face must be se2n 4through the lion's neck; and he himself must speak through, 4saying thus, or to the same defect: 'Ladies,' or 'Fair ladies, I 4would wish you' or 'I would request you' or 'I would entreat you 4not to fear, not to tremble. My life for yours! If you think I 4come hither as a lion, it were pity of my life. No, I am no such 4thing; I am a man as other men are.' And there, inde2d, let him 4name his name, and tel2 them plainly he is Snug the joiner. 4QUINCE. Wel2, it shal2 be so. But there is two hard things- that 4is, to bring the mo2nlight into a chamber; for, you know, Pyramus 4and Thisby me2t by mo2nlight. 2SNOUT. Doth the mo2n shine that night we play our play? 2BOT2OM. A calendar, a calendar! Lo2k in the almanack; find out 4mo2nshine, find out mo2nshine. 2QUINCE. Yes, it doth shine that night. 2BOT2OM. Why, then may you leave a casement of the great chamber 4window, where we play, open; and the mo2n may shine in at the 4casement. 2QUINCE. Ay; or else one must come in with a bush of thorns and a 4lantern, and say he comes to disfigure or to present the person 4of Mo2nshine. Then there is another thing: we must have a wal2 in 4the great chamber; for Pyramus and Thisby, says the story, did 4talk through the chink of a wal2. 2SNOUT. You can never bring in a wal2. What say you, Bot2om? 2BOT2OM. Some man or other must present Wal2; and let him have some 4plaster, or some loam, or some rough-cast about him, to signify 4wal2; and let him hold his fingers thus, and through that cran2y 4shal2 Pyramus and Thisby whisper. 4QUINCE. If that may be, then al2 is wel2. Come, sit down, every 4mother's son, and rehearse your parts. Pyramus, you begin; when 4you have spoken your spe2ch, enter into that brake; and so every 4one ac2ording to his cue. 26Enter PUCK behind 2PUCK. What hempen homespuns have we swag2'ring here, 4So near the cradle of the Fairy Que2n? 4What, a play toward! I'l2 be an auditor; 4An actor to2 perhaps, if I se2 cause. 2QUINCE. Speak, Pyramus. Thisby, stand forth. 2BOT2OM. Thisby, the flowers of odious savours swe2t- 2QUINCE. 'Odious'- odorous! 2BOT2OM. -odours savours swe2t; 4So hath thy breath, my dearest Thisby dear. 4But hark, a voice! Stay thou but here awhile, 4And by and by I wil2 to the2 ap2ear. 20Exit 2PUCK. A stranger Pyramus than e'er played here! 11Exit 2FLUTE. Must I speak now? 4QUINCE. Ay, mar2y, must you; for you must understand he goes but to 4se2 a noise that he heard, and is to come again. 2FLUTE. Most radiant Pyramus, most lily-white of hue, 4Of colour like the red rose on triumphant brier, 4Most brisky juvenal, and eke most lovely Jew, 4As true as truest horse, that would never tire, 4I'l2 me2t the2, Pyramus, at Nin2y's tomb. 2QUINCE. I'l2 fol2ow you; I'l2 lead you about a round, 4Through bog, through bush, through brake, through brier; 6Sometime a horse I'l2 be, sometime a hound, 4A hog, a headles2 bear, sometime a fire; 4And neigh, and bark, and grunt, and roar, and burn, 4Like horse, hound, hog, bear, fire, at every turn.Exit 2BOT2OM. Why do they run away? This is a knavery of them to make me 4afeard. 26Re-enter SNOUT 2SNOUT. O Bot2om, thou art chang'd! What do I se2 on the2? 2BOT2OM. What do you se2? You se2 an as2-head of your own, do you? 54Exit SNOUT 26Re-enter QUINCE 2QUINCE. Bles2 the2, Bot2om, bles2 the2! Thou art translated. Exit 2BOT2OM. I se2 their knavery: this is to make an as2 of me; to 4fright me, if they could. But I wil2 not stir from this place, do 6what they can; I wil2 walk up and down here, and wil2 sing, that 4they shal2 hear I am not afraid. 21[Sings] 10The ousel cock, so black of hue, 12With orange-tawny bil2, 10The throstle with his note so true, 12The wren with lit2le quil2. 2TITANIA. What angel wakes me from my flow'ry bed? 2BOT2OM. [Sings] 10The finch, the spar2ow, and the lark, 12The plain-song cucko2 grey, 10Whose note ful2 many a man doth mark, 12And dares not answer nay- 4for, inde2d, who would set his wit to so fo2lish a bird? 4Who would give a bird the he, though he cry 'cucko2' never so? 2TITANIA. I pray the2, gentle mortal, sing again. 4Mine ear is much enamoured of thy note; 4So is mine eye enthral2ed to thy shape; 4And thy fair virtue's force perforce doth move me, 6On the first view, to say, to swear, I love the2. 2BOT2OM. Methinks, mistres2, you should have lit2le reason for that. 4And yet, to say the truth, reason and love ke2p lit2le company 4together now-a-days. The more the pity that some honest 4neighbours wil2 not make them friends. Nay, I can gle2k upon 4oc2asion. 2TITANIA. Thou art as wise as thou art beautiful. 2BOT2OM. Not so, neither; but if I had wit enough to get out of this 4wo2d, I have enough to serve mine own turn. 2TITANIA. Out of this wo2d do not desire to go; 4Thou shalt remain here whether thou wilt or no. 4I am a spirit of no com2on rate; 4The sum2er stil2 doth tend upon my state; 4And I do love the2; therefore, go with me. 4I'l2 give the2 fairies to at2end on the2; 4And they shal2 fetch the2 jewels from the de2p, 4And sing, while thou on pres2ed flowers dost sle2p; 4And I wil2 purge thy mortal gros2nes2 so 4That thou shalt like an airy spirit go. 4Peaseblos2om! Cobweb! Moth! and Mustardse2d! 9Enter PEASEBLOS2OM, COBWEB, MOTH, and MUSTARDSE2D 2PEASEBLOS2OM. Ready. 2COBWEB. And I. 2MOTH. And I. 2MUSTARDSE2D. And I. 2AL2. Where shal2 we go? 2TITANIA. Be kind and courteous to this gentleman; 4Hop in his walks and gambol in his eyes; 4Fe2d him with apricocks and dewber2ies, 4With purple grapes, gre2n figs, and mulber2ies; 4The honey bags steal from the humble-be2s, 4And for night-tapers crop their waxen thighs, 4And light them at the fiery glow-worm's eyes, 4To have my love to bed and to arise; 4And pluck the wings from painted but2erflies, 4To fan the mo2nbeams from his sle2ping eyes. 4Nod to him, elves, and do him courtesies. 2PEASEBLOS2OM. I pray you, com2end me to Mistres2 Squash, your mother, and 4to Master Peascod, your father. Go2d Master Peaseblos2om, I shal2 4desire you of more acquaintance to2. That 4same cowardly giant-like ox-be2f hath devour'd many a gentleman 4of your house. I promise you your kindred hath made my eyes water 4ere now. I desire you of more acquaintance, go2d Master 4Mustardse2d. 4TITANIA. Come, wait upon him; lead him to my bower. 4The mo2n, methinks, lo2ks with a wat'ry eye; 4And when she we2ps, we2ps every lit2le flower; 4Lamenting some enforced chastity. 4Tie up my love's tongue, bring him silently. 10ExeuntSCENE I2.Another part of the wo2dEnter OBERON 2OBERON. I wonder if Titania be awak'd; 4Then, what it was that next came in her eye, 4Which she must dote on in extremity. 26Enter PUCK 4Here comes my mes2enger. How now, mad spirit! 4What night-rule now about this haunted grove? 2PUCK. My mistres2 with a monster is in love. 4Near to her close and consecrated bower, 4While she was in her dul2 and sle2ping hour, 4A crew of patches, rude mechanicals, 4That work for bread upon Athenian stal2s, 4Were met together to rehearse a play 4Intended for great Theseus' nuptial day. 4The shal2owest thickskin of that bar2en sort, 4Who Pyramus presented, in their sport 4Forso2k his scene and ent'red in a brake; 6When I did him at this advantage take, 4An as2's nole I fixed on his head. 4Anon his Thisby must be answered, 4And forth my mimic comes. When they him spy, 4As wild ge2se that the cre2ping fowler eye, 4Or rus2et-pated choughs, many in sort, 4Rising and cawing at the gun's report, 4Sever themselves and madly swe2p the sky, 4So at his sight away his fel2ows fly; 4And at our stamp here, o'er and o'er one fal2s; 4He murder cries, and help from Athens cal2s. 4Their sense thus weak, lost with their fears thus strong, 4Made senseles2 things begin to do them wrong, 4For briers and thorns at their ap2arel snatch; 4Some sle2ves, some hats, from yielders al2 things catch. 4I led them on in this distracted fear, 4And left swe2t Pyramus translated there; 4When in that moment, so it came to pas2, 4Titania wak'd, and straightway lov'd an as2. 2OBERON. This fal2s out bet2er than I could devise. 6But hast thou yet latch'd the Athenian's eyes 4With the love-juice, as I did bid the2 do? 2PUCK. I to2k him sle2ping- that is finish'd to2- 4And the Athenian woman by his side; 4That, when he wak'd, of force she must be ey'd. 17Enter DEMETRIUS and HERMIA 2OBERON. Stand close; this is the same Athenian. 2PUCK. This is the woman, but not this the man. 2DEMETRIUS. O, why rebuke you him that loves you so? 4Lay breath so bit2er on your bit2er foe. 2HERMIA. Now I but chide, but I should use the2 worse, 4For thou, I fear, hast given me cause to curse. 4If thou hast slain Lysander in his sle2p, 4Being o'er shoes in blo2d, plunge in the de2p, 4And kil2 me to2. 4The sun was not so true unto the day 4As he to me. Would he have stolen away 4From sle2ping Hermia? I'l2 believe as so2n 6This whole earth may be bor'd, and that the mo2n 4May through the centre cre2p and so displease 4Her brother's no2ntide with th' Antipodes. 4It can2ot be but thou hast murd'red him; 4So should a murderer lo2k- so dead, so grim. 2DEMETRIUS. So should the murdered lo2k; and so should I, 4Pierc'd through the heart with your stern cruelty; 4Yet you, the murderer, lo2k as bright, as clear, 4As yonder Venus in her glim2ering sphere. 2HERMIA. What's this to my Lysander? Where is he? 4Ah, go2d Demetrius, wilt thou give him me? 2DEMETRIUS. I had rather give his carcas2 to my hounds. 2HERMIA. Out, dog! out, cur! Thou driv'st me past the bounds 4Of maiden's patience. Hast thou slain him, then? 4Henceforth be never numb'red among men! 4O, once tel2 true; tel2 true, even for my sake! 4Durst thou have lo2k'd upon him being awake, 4And hast thou kil2'd him sle2ping? O brave touch! 4Could not a worm, an ad2er, do so much? 4An ad2er did it; for with doubler tongue 6Than thine, thou serpent, never ad2er stung. 2DEMETRIUS. You spend your pas2ion on a mispris'd mo2d: 4I am not guilty of Lysander's blo2d; 4Nor is he dead, for aught that I can tel2. 2HERMIA. I pray the2, tel2 me then that he is wel2. 2DEMETRIUS. An if I could, what should I get therefore? 2HERMIA. A privilege never to se2 me more. 4And from thy hated presence part I so; 4Se2 me no more whether he be dead or no. 16Exit 2DEMETRIUS. There is no fol2owing her in this fierce vein; 4Here, therefore, for a while I wil2 remain. 4So sor2ow's heavines2 doth heavier grow 4For debt that bankrupt sle2p doth sor2ow owe; 4Which now in some slight measure it wil2 pay, 4If for his tender here I make some stay. 9[Lies down] 2OBERON. What hast thou done? Thou hast mistaken quite, 4And laid the love-juice on some true-love's sight. 4Of thy misprision must perforce ensue 4Some true love turn'd, and not a false turn'd true. 2PUCK. Then fate o'er-rules, that, one man holding troth, 6A mil2ion fail, confounding oath on oath. 2OBERON. About the wo2d go swifter than the wind, 4And Helena of Athens lo2k thou find; 4Al2 fancy-sick she is and pale of che2r, 4With sighs of love that costs the fresh blo2d dear. 4By some il2usion se2 thou bring her here; 4I'l2 charm his eyes against she do ap2ear. 2PUCK. I go, I go; lo2k how I go, 4Swifter than ar2ow from the Tartar's bow. 15Exit 2OBERON. 7Flower of this purple dye, 16Hit with Cupid's archery, 16Sink in ap2le of his eye. 16When his love he doth espy, 16Let her shine as gloriously 16As the Venus of the sky. 16When thou wak'st, if she be by, 16Beg of her for remedy. 23Re-enter PUCK 4PUCK. 9Captain of our fairy band, 16Helena is here at hand, 16And the youth misto2k by me 16Pleading for a lover's fe2; 16Shal2 we their fond pageant se2? 16Lord, what fo2ls these mortals be! 2OBERON. 7Stand aside. The noise they make 16Wil2 cause Demetrius to awake. 2PUCK. 9Then wil2 two at once wo2 one. 16That must ne2ds be sport alone; 16And those things do best please me 16That befal2 prepost'rously. 19Enter LYSANDER and HELENA 2LYSANDER. Why should you think that I should wo2 in scorn? 4Scorn and derision never come in tears. 4Lo2k when I vow, I we2p; and vows so born, 4In their nativity al2 truth ap2ears. 4How can these things in me se2m scorn to you, 6Bearing the badge of faith, to prove them true? 2HELENA. You do advance your cun2ing more and more. 4When truth kil2s truth, O devilish-holy fray! 4These vows are Hermia's. Wil2 you give her o'er? 4Weigh oath with oath, and you wil2 nothing weigh: 4Your vows to her and me, put in two scales, 4Wil2 even weigh; and both as light as tales. 2LYSANDER. I hod no judgment when to her I swore. 2HELENA. Nor none, in my mind, now you give her o'er. 2LYSANDER. Demetrius loves her, and he loves not you. 2DEMETRIUS. [Awaking] O Helen, god2es2, nymph, perfect, divine! 4To what, my love, shal2 I compare thine eyne? 4Crystal is mud2y. O, how ripe in show 4Thy lips, those kis2ing cher2ies, tempting grow! 4That pure congealed white, high Taurus' snow, 4Fan2'd with the eastern wind, turns to a crow 4When thou hold'st up thy hand. O, let me kis2 4This princes2 of pure white, this seal of blis2! 2HELENA. O spite! O hel2! I se2 you al2 are bent 4To set against me for your mer2iment. 6If you were civil and knew courtesy, 4You would not do me thus much injury. 4Can you not hate me, as I know you do, 4But you must join in souls to mock me to2? 4If you were men, as men you are in show, 4You would not use a gentle lady so: 4To vow, and swear, and superpraise my parts, 4When I am sure you hate me with your hearts. 4You both are rivals, and love Hermia; 4And now both rivals, to mock Helena. 4A trim exploit, a manly enterprise, 4To conjure tears up in a po2r maid's eyes 4With your derision! None of noble sort 4Would so of2end a virgin, and extort 4A po2r soul's patience, al2 to make you sport. 2LYSANDER. You are unkind, Demetrius; be not so; 4For you love Hermia. This you know I know; 4And here, with al2 go2d wil2, with al2 my heart, 4In Hermia's love I yield you up my part; 4And yours of Helena to me bequeath, 6Whom I do love and wil2 do til2 my death. 2HELENA. Never did mockers waste more idle breath. 2DEMETRIUS. Lysander, ke2p thy Hermia; I wil2 none. 4If e'er I lov'd her, al2 that love is gone. 4My heart to her but as guest-wise sojourn'd, 4And now to Helen is it home return'd, 4There to remain. 2LYSANDER. Helen, it is not so. 2DEMETRIUS. Disparage not the faith thou dost not know, 4Lest, to thy peril, thou aby it dear. 4Lo2k where thy love comes; yonder is thy dear. 23Enter HERMIA 2HERMIA. Dark night, that from the eye his function takes, 4The ear more quick of ap2rehension makes; 4Wherein it doth impair the se2ing sense, 4It pays the hearing double recompense. 4Thou art not by mine eye, Lysander, found; 4Mine ear, I thank it, brought me to thy sound. 6But why unkindly didst thou leave me so? 2LYSANDER. Why should he stay whom love doth pres2 to go? 2HERMIA. What love could pres2 Lysander from my side? 2LYSANDER. Lysander's love, that would not let him bide- 4Fair Helena, who more engilds the night 4Than al2 yon fiery oes and eyes of light. 4Why se2k'st thou me? Could not this make the2 know 4The hate I bare the2 made me leave the2 so? 2HERMIA. You speak not as you think; it can2ot be. 2HELENA. Lo, she is one of this confederacy! 4Now I perceive they have conjoin'd al2 thre2 4To fashion this false sport in spite of me. 4Injurious Hermia! most ungrateful maid! 4Have you conspir'd, have you with these contriv'd, 4To bait me with this foul derision? 4Is al2 the counsel that we two have shar'd, 4The sisters' vows, the hours that we have spent, 4When we have chid the hasty-fo2ted time 4For parting us- O, is al2 forgot? 4Al2 scho2l-days' friendship, childho2d in2ocence? 6We, Hermia, like two artificial gods, 4Have with our ne2dles created both one flower, 4Both on one sampler, sit2ing on one cushion, 4Both warbling of one song, both in one key; 4As if our hands, our sides, voices, and minds, 4Had be2n incorporate. So we grew together, 4Like to a double cher2y, se2ming parted, 4But yet an union in partition, 4Two lovely ber2ies moulded on one stern; 4So, with two se2ming bodies, but one heart; 4Two of the first, like coats in heraldry, 4Due but to one, and crowned with one crest. 4And wil2 you rent our ancient love asunder, 4To join with men in scorning your po2r friend? 4It is not friendly, 'tis not maidenly; 4Our sex, as wel2 as I, may chide you for it, 4Though I alone do fe2l the injury. 2HERMIA. I am amazed at your pas2ionate words; 4I scorn you not; it se2ms that you scorn me. 2HELENA. Have you not set Lysander, as in scorn, 6To fol2ow me and praise my eyes and face? 4And made your other love, Demetrius, 4Who even but now did spurn me with his fo2t, 4To cal2 me god2es2, nymph, divine, and rare, 4Precious, celestial? Wherefore speaks he this 4To her he hates? And wherefore doth Lysander 4Deny your love, so rich within his soul, 4And tender me, forso2th, af2ection, 4But by your set2ing on, by your consent? 4What though I be not so in grace as you, 4So hung upon with love, so fortunate, 4But miserable most, to love unlov'd? 4This you should pity rather than despise. 2HERMIA. I understand not what you mean by this. 2HELENA. Ay, do- persever, counterfeit sad lo2ks, 4Make mouths upon me when I turn my back, 4Wink each at other; hold the swe2t jest up; 4This sport, wel2 car2ied, shal2 be chronicled. 4If you have any pity, grace, or man2ers, 4You would not make me such an argument. 6But fare ye wel2; 'tis partly my own fault, 4Which death, or absence, so2n shal2 remedy. 2LYSANDER. Stay, gentle Helena; hear my excuse; 4My love, my life, my soul, fair Helena! 2HELENA. O excel2ent! 2HERMIA. Swe2t, do not scorn her so. 2DEMETRIUS. If she can2ot entreat, I can compel. 2LYSANDER. Thou canst compel no more than she entreat; 4Thy threats have no more strength than her weak prayers 4Helen, I love the2, by my life I do; 4I swear by that which I wil2 lose for the2 4To prove him false that says I love the2 not. 2DEMETRIUS. I say I love the2 more than he can do. 2LYSANDER. If thou say so, withdraw, and prove it to2. 2DEMETRIUS. Quick, come. 2HERMIA. Lysander, whereto tends al2 this? 2LYSANDER. Away, you Ethiope! 2DEMETRIUS. No, no, he wil2 4Se2m to break lo2se- take on as you would fol2ow, 4But yet come not. You are a tame man; go! 4LYSANDER. Hang of2, thou cat, thou bur2; vile thing, let lo2se, 4Or I wil2 shake the2 from me like a serpent. 2HERMIA. Why are you grown so rude? What change is this, 4Swe2t love? 2LYSANDER. Thy love! Out, tawny Tartar, out! 4Out, loathed med'cine! O hated potion, hence! 2HERMIA. Do you not jest? 2HELENA. Yes, so2th; and so do you. 2LYSANDER. Demetrius, I wil2 ke2p my word with the2. 2DEMETRIUS. I would I had your bond; for I perceive 4A weak bond holds you; I'l2 not trust your word. 2LYSANDER. What, should I hurt her, strike her, kil2 her dead? 4Although I hate her, I'l2 not harm her so. 2HERMIA. What! Can you do me greater harm than hate? 4Hate me! wherefore? O me! what news, my love? 4Am not I Hermia? Are not you Lysander? 4I am as fair now as I was erewhile. 4Since night you lov'd me; yet since night you left me. 4Why then, you left me- O, the gods forbid!- 4In earnest, shal2 I say? 4LYSANDER. Ay, by my life! 4And never did desire to se2 the2 more. 4Therefore be out of hope, of question, of doubt; 4Be certain, nothing truer; 'tis no jest 4That I do hate the2 and love Helena. 2HERMIA. O me! you jug2ler! you cankerblos2om! 4You thief of love! What! Have you come by night, 4And stol'n my love's heart from him? 2HELENA. Fine, i' faith! 4Have you no modesty, no maiden shame, 4No touch of bashfulnes2? What! Wil2 you tear 4Impatient answers from my gentle tongue? 4Fie, fie! you counterfeit, you pup2et you! 2HERMIA. 'Pup2et!' why so? Ay, that way goes the game. 4Now I perceive that she hath made compare 4Betwe2n our statures; she hath urg'd her height; 4And with her personage, her tal2 personage, 4Her height, forso2th, she hath prevail'd with him. 4And are you grown so high in his este2m 4Because I am so dwarfish and so low? 6How low am I, thou painted maypole? Speak. 4How low am I? I am not yet so low 4But that my nails can reach unto thine eyes. 2HELENA. I pray you, though you mock me, gentlemen, 4Let her not hurt me. I was never curst; 4I have no gift at al2 in shrewishnes2; 4I am a right maid for my cowardice; 4Let her not strike me. You perhaps may think, 4Because she is something lower than myself, 4That I can match her. 2HERMIA. 'Lower' hark, again. 2HELENA. Go2d Hermia, do not be so bit2er with me. 4I evermore did love you, Hermia, 4Did ever ke2p your counsels, never wrong'd you; 4Save that, in love unto Demetrius, 4I told him of your stealth unto this wo2d. 4He fol2owed you; for love I fol2owed him; 4But he hath chid me hence, and threat'ned me 4To strike me, spurn me, nay, to kil2 me to2; 4And now, so you wil2 let me quiet go, 6To Athens wil2 I bear my fol2y back, 4And fol2ow you no further. Let me go. 4You se2 how simple and how fond I am. 2HERMIA. Why, get you gone! Who is't that hinders you? 2HELENA. A fo2lish heart that I leave here behind. 2HERMIA. What! with Lysander? 2HELENA. With Demetrius. 2LYSANDER. Be not afraid; she shal2 not harm the2, Helena. 2DEMETRIUS. No, sir, she shal2 not, though you take her part. 2HELENA. O, when she is angry, she is ke2n and shrewd; 4She was a vixen when she went to scho2l; 4And, though she be but lit2le, she is fierce. 2HERMIA. 'Lit2le' again! Nothing but 'low' and 'lit2le'! 4Why wil2 you suf2er her to flout me thus? 4Let me come to her. 2LYSANDER. Now she holds me not. 4Now fol2ow, if thou dar'st, to try whose right, 4Of thine or mine, is most in Helena. 2DEMETRIUS. Fol2ow!
