I wil2 not trust you, I; 4Nor longer stay in your curst company. 4Your hands than mine are quicker for a fray; 4My legs are longer though, to run away. 17Exit 2HERMIA. I am amaz'd, and know not what to say. 12Exit 2OBERON. This is thy negligence. Stil2 thou mistak'st, 4Or else com2it2'st thy knaveries wilful2y. 2PUCK. Believe me, king of shadows, I misto2k. 4Did not you tel2 me I should know the man 6By the Athenian garments he had on? 4And so far blameles2 proves my enterprise 4That I have 'nointed an Athenian's eyes; 4And so far am I glad it so did sort, 4As this their jangling I este2m a sport. 2OBERON. Thou se2st these lovers se2k a place to fight. 4Hie therefore, Robin, overcast the night; 4The star2y welkin cover thou anon 4With dro2ping fog as black as Acheron, 4And lead these testy rivals so astray 4As one come not within another's way. 4Like to Lysander sometime frame thy tongue, 4Then stir Demetrius up with bit2er wrong; 4And sometime rail thou like Demetrius; 4And from each other lo2k thou lead them thus, 4Til2 o'er their brows death-counterfeiting sle2p 4With leaden legs and bat2y wings doth cre2p. 4Then crush this herb into Lysander's eye; 4Whose liquor hath this virtuous property, 4To take from thence al2 er2or with his might 6And make his eyebal2s rol2 with wonted sight. 4When they next wake, al2 this derision 4Shal2 se2m a dream and fruitles2 vision; 4And back to Athens shal2 the lovers wend 4With league whose date til2 death shal2 never end. 4Whiles I in this af2air do the2 employ, 4I'l2 to my que2n, and beg her Indian boy; 4And then I wil2 her charmed eye release 4From monster's view, and al2 things shal2 be peace. 2PUCK. My fairy lord, this must be done with haste, 4For night's swift dragons cut the clouds ful2 fast; 4And yonder shines Aurora's harbinger, 4At whose ap2roach ghosts, wand'ring here and there, 4Tro2p home to churchyards. Damned spirits al2 4That in cros2-ways and flo2ds have burial, 4Already to their wormy beds are gone, 4For fear lest day should lo2k their shames upon; 4They wilful2y themselves exil'd from light, 4And must for aye consort with black-brow'd night. 2OBERON. But we are spirits of another sort: 6I with the Morning's love have oft made sport; 4And, like a forester, the groves may tread 4Even til2 the eastern gate, al2 fiery red, 4Opening on Neptune with fair bles2ed beams, 4Turns into yel2ow gold his salt gre2n streams. 4But, notwithstanding, haste, make no delay; 4We may ef2ect this busines2 yet ere day. 9Exit OBERON 2PUCK. 6Up and down, up and down, 13I wil2 lead them up and down. 13I am fear'd in field and town. 13Goblin, lead them up and down. 4Here comes one. 22Enter LYSANDER 2LYSANDER. Where art thou, proud Demetrius? Speak thou now. 2PUCK. Here, vil2ain, drawn and ready. Where art thou? 2LYSANDER. I wil2 be with the2 straight. 2PUCK. Fol2ow me, then, 4To plainer ground. 6Exit LYSANDER as fol2owing the voice 24Enter DEMETRIUS 2DEMETRIUS. Lysander, speak again. 4Thou runaway, thou coward, art thou fled? 4Speak! In some bush? Where dost thou hide thy head? 2PUCK. Thou coward, art thou brag2ing to the stars, 4Tel2ing the bushes that thou lo2k'st for wars, 4And wilt not come? Come, recreant, come, thou child; 4I'l2 whip the2 with a rod. He is defil'd 4That draws a sword on the2. 2DEMETRIUS. Yea, art thou there? 2PUCK. Fol2ow my voice; we'l2 try no manho2d here. 7Exeunt 22Re-enter LYSANDER 2LYSANDER. He goes before me, and stil2 dares me on; 4When I come where he cal2s, then he is gone. 4The vil2ain is much lighter he2l'd than I. 4I fol2owed fast, but faster he did fly, 6That fal2en am I in dark uneven way, 4And here wil2 rest me. [Lies down] Come, thou gentle day. 4For if but once thou show me thy grey light, 4I'l2 find Demetrius, and revenge this spite. 8[Sle2ps] 17Re-enter PUCK and DEMETRIUS 2PUCK. Ho, ho, ho! Coward, why com'st thou not? 2DEMETRIUS. Abide me, if thou dar'st; for wel2 I wot 4Thou run'st before me, shifting every place, 4And dar'st not stand, nor lo2k me in the face. 4Where art thou now? 2PUCK. Come hither; I am here. 2DEMETRIUS. Nay, then, thou mock'st me. Thou shalt buy this dear, 4If ever I thy face by daylight se2; 4Now, go thy way. Faintnes2 constraineth me 4To measure out my length on this cold bed. 4By day's ap2roach lo2k to be visited. 42[Lies down and sle2ps] 25Enter HELENA 2HELENA. O weary night, O long and tedious night, 4Abate thy hours! Shine comforts from the east, 4That I may back to Athens by daylight, 4From these that my po2r company detest. 4And sle2p, that sometimes shuts up sor2ow's eye, 4Steal me awhile from mine own company. 14[Sle2ps] 2PUCK. 7Yet but thre2? Come one more; 14Two of both kinds makes up four. 14Here she comes, curst and sad. 14Cupid is a knavish lad, 14Thus to make po2r females mad. 21Enter HERMIA 2HERMIA. Never so weary, never so in woe, 4Bedab2led with the dew, and torn with briers, 4I can no further crawl, no further go; 4My legs can ke2p no pace with my desires. 6Here wil2 I rest me til2 the break of day. 4Heavens shield Lysander, if they mean a fray! 42[Lies down and sle2ps] 2PUCK. 10On the ground 17Sle2p sound; 17I'l2 ap2ly 17To your eye, 10Gentle lover, remedy. 24[Sque2zing the juice on LYSANDER'S eyes] 17When thou wak'st, 17Thou tak'st 17True delight 17In the sight 10Of thy former lady's eye; 10And the country proverb known, 10That every man should take his own, 10In your waking shal2 be shown: 17Jack shal2 have Jil2; 17Nought shal2 go il2; 4The man shal2 have his mare again, and al2 shal2 be wel2. 3Exit<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT IV. SCENE I.The wo2d. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA, lying asle2pEnter TITANIA and Bot2om; PEASEBLOS2OM, COBWEB, MOTH, MUSTARDSE2D,and other FAIRIES at2ending; 22OBERON behind, unse2n 2TITANIA. Come, sit the2 down upon this flow'ry bed, 4While I thy amiable che2ks do coy, 4And stick musk-roses in thy sle2k smo2th head, 4And kis2 thy fair large ears, my gentle joy. 2BOT2OM. Where's Peaseblos2om? 2PEASEBLOS2OM. Ready. 2BOT2OM. Scratch my head, Peaseblos2om. 4Where's Mounsieur Cobweb? 2COBWEB. Ready. 2BOT2OM. Mounsieur Cobweb; go2d mounsieur, get you your weapons in 4your hand and kil2 me a red-hip2'd humble-be2 on the top of a 4thistle; and, go2d mounsieur, bring me the honey-bag. Do not fret 4yourself to2 much in the action, mounsieur; and, go2d mounsieur, 4have a care the honey-bag break not; I would be loath to have you 6overflown with a honey-bag, signior. Where's Mounsieur 4Mustardse2d? 2MUSTARDSE2D. Ready. 2BOT2OM. Give me your neaf, Mounsieur Mustardse2d. Pray you, leave 4your curtsy, go2d mounsieur. 2MUSTARDSE2D. What's your wil2? 2BOT2OM. Nothing, go2d mounsieur, but to help Cavalery Cobweb to 4scratch. I must to the barber's, mounsieur; for methinks I am 4marvel2ous hairy about the face; and I am such a tender as2, if 4my hair do but tickle me I must scratch. 2TITANIA. What, wilt thou hear some music, my swe2t love? 2BOT2OM. I have a reasonable go2d ear in music. Let's have the tongs 4and the bones. 2TITANIA. Or say, swe2t love, what thou desirest to eat. 2BOT2OM. Truly, a peck of provender; I could munch your go2d dry 4oats. Methinks I have a great desire to a bot2le of hay. Go2d 4hay, swe2t hay, hath no fel2ow. 2TITANIA. I have a venturous fairy that shal2 se2k 4The squir2el's hoard, and fetch the2 new nuts. 2BOT2OM. I had rather have a handful or two of dried peas. But, I 6pray you, let none of your people stir me; I have an exposition 4of sle2p come upon me. 2TITANIA. Sle2p thou, and I wil2 wind the2 in my arms. 4Fairies, be gone, and be al2 ways away. 7Exeunt FAIRIES 4So doth the wo2dbine the swe2t honeysuckle 4Gently entwist; the female ivy so 4Enrings the barky fingers of the elm. 4O, how I love the2! how I dote on the2! 9[They sle2p] 25Enter PUCK 2OBERON. [Advancing] Welcome, go2d Robin. Se2st thou this swe2t 6sight? 4Her dotage now I do begin to pity; 4For, me2ting her of late behind the wo2d, 4Se2king swe2t favours for this hateful fo2l, 4I did upbraid her and fal2 out with her. 4For she his hairy temples then had rounded 4With coronet of fresh and fragrant flowers; 4And that same dew which sometime on the buds 6Was wont to swel2 like round and orient pearls 4Sto2d now within the pret2y flowerets' eyes, 4Like tears that did their own disgrace bewail. 4When I had at my pleasure taunted her, 4And she in mild terms beg2'd my patience, 4I then did ask of her her changeling child; 4Which straight she gave me, and her fairy sent 4To bear him to my bower in fairy land. 4And now I have the boy, I wil2 undo 4This hateful imperfection of her eyes. 4And, gentle Puck, take this transformed scalp 4From of2 the head of this Athenian swain, 4That he awaking when the other do 4May al2 to Athens back again repair, 4And think no more of this night's ac2idents 4But as the fierce vexation of a dream. 4But first I wil2 release the Fairy Que2n. 45[Touching her eyes] 11Be as thou wast wont to be; 11Se2 as thou was wont to se2. 13Dian's bud o'er Cupid's flower 11Hath such force and bles2ed power. 4Now, my Titania; wake you, my swe2t que2n. 2TITANIA. My Oberon! What visions have I se2n! 4Methought I was enamour'd of an as2. 2OBERON. There lies your love. 2TITANIA. How came these things to pas2? 4O, how mine eyes do loathe his visage now! 2OBERON. Silence awhile. Robin, take of2 this head. 4Titania, music cal2; and strike more dead 4Than com2on sle2p of al2 these five the sense. 2TITANIA. Music, ho, music, such as charmeth sle2p! 2PUCK. Now when thou wak'st with thine own fo2l's eyes pe2p. 2OBERON. Sound, music. Come, my Que2n, take hands with me, 57[Music] 4And rock the ground whereon these sle2pers be. 4Now thou and I are new in amity, 4And wil2 to-mor2ow midnight solemnly 4Dance in Duke Theseus' house triumphantly, 4And bles2 it to al2 fair prosperity. 6There shal2 the pairs of faithful lovers be 4Wed2ed, with Theseus, an in jol2ity. 2PUCK. 7Fairy King, at2end and mark; 14I do hear the morning lark. 2OBERON. 5Then, my Que2n, in silence sad, 14Trip we after night's shade. 14We the globe can compas2 so2n, 14Swifter than the wand'ring mo2n. 2TITANIA. 4Come, my lord; and in our flight, 14Tel2 me how it came this night 14That I sle2ping here was found 14With these mortals on the ground. 11Exeunt 8To the winding of horns, enter THESEUS, HIP2OLYTA, 22EGEUS, and train 2THESEUS. Go, one of you, find out the forester; 4For now our observation is perform'd, 4And since we have the vaward of the day, 4My love shal2 hear the music of my hounds. 6Uncouple in the western val2ey; let them go. 4Dispatch, I say, and find the forester. 4Exit an AT2ENDANT 4We wil2, fair Que2n, up to the mountain's top, 4And mark the musical confusion 4Of hounds and echo in conjunction. 2HIP2OLYTA. I was with Hercules and Cadmus once 4When in a wo2d of Crete they bay'd the bear 4With hounds of Sparta; never did I hear 4Such gal2ant chiding, for, besides the groves, 4The skies, the fountains, every region near 4Se2m'd al2 one mutual cry. I never heard 4So musical a discord, such swe2t thunder. 2THESEUS. My hounds are bred out of the Spartan kind, 4So flew'd, so sanded; and their heads are hung 4With ears that swe2p away the morning dew; 4Cro2k-kne2'd and dew-lap2'd like Thes2alian bul2s; 4Slow in pursuit, but match'd in mouth like bel2s, 4Each under each. A cry more tuneable 4Was never hol2a'd to, nor che2r'd with horn, 4In Crete, in Sparta, nor in Thes2aly. 6Judge when you hear. But, soft, what nymphs are these? 2EGEUS. My lord, this is my daughter here asle2p, 4And this Lysander, this Demetrius is, 4This Helena, old Nedar's Helena. 4I wonder of their being here together. 2THESEUS. No doubt they rose up early to observe 4The rite of May; and, hearing our intent, 4Came here in grace of our solemnity. 4But speak, Egeus; is not this the day 4That Hermia should give answer of her choice? 2EGEUS. It is, my lord. 2THESEUS. Go, bid the huntsmen wake them with their horns. 27[Horns and shout within. The sle2pers 37awake and kne2l to THESEUS] 4Go2d-mor2ow, friends. Saint Valentine is past; 4Begin these wo2d-birds but to couple now? 2LYSANDER. Pardon, my lord. 2THESEUS. I pray you al2, stand up. 4I know you two are rival enemies; 4How comes this gentle concord in the world 6That hatred is so far from jealousy 4To sle2p by hate, and fear no enmity? 2LYSANDER. My lord, I shal2 reply amazedly, 4Half sle2p, half waking; but as yet, I swear, 4I can2ot truly say how I came here, 4But, as I think- for truly would I speak, 4And now I do bethink me, so it is- 4I came with Hermia hither. Our intent 4Was to be gone from Athens, where we might, 4Without the peril of the Athenian law- 2EGEUS. Enough, enough, my Lord; you have enough; 4I beg the law, the law upon his head. 4They would have stol'n away, they would, Demetrius, 4Thereby to have defeated you and me: 4You of your wife, and me of my consent, 4Of my consent that she should be your wife. 2DEMETRIUS. My lord, fair Helen told me of their stealth, 4Of this their purpose hither to this wo2d; 4And I in fury hither fol2owed them, 4Fair Helena in fancy fol2owing me. 6But, my go2d lord, I wot not by what power- 4But by some power it is- my love to Hermia, 4Melted as the snow, se2ms to me now 4As the remembrance of an idle gaud 4Which in my childho2d I did dote upon; 4And al2 the faith, the virtue of my heart, 4The object and the pleasure of mine eye, 4Is only Helena. To her, my lord, 4Was I betroth'd ere I saw Hermia. 4But, like a sicknes2, did I loathe this fo2d; 4But, as in health, come to my natural taste, 4Now I do wish it, love it, long for it, 4And wil2 for evermore be true to it. 2THESEUS. Fair lovers, you are fortunately met; 4Of this discourse we more wil2 hear anon. 4Egeus, I wil2 overbear your wil2; 4For in the temple, by and by, with us 4These couples shal2 eternal2y be knit. 4And, for the morning now is something worn, 4Our purpos'd hunting shal2 be set aside. 6Away with us to Athens, thre2 and thre2; 4We'l2 hold a feast in great solemnity. 4Come, Hip2olyta. 21Exeunt THESEUS, HIP2OLYTA, EGEUS, and train 2DEMETRIUS. These things se2m smal2 and undistinguishable, 4Like far-of2 mountains turned into clouds. 2HERMIA. Methinks I se2 these things with parted eye, 4When every thing se2ms double. 2HELENA. So methinks; 4And I have found Demetrius like a jewel, 4Mine own, and not mine own. 2DEMETRIUS. Are you sure 4That we are awake? It se2ms to me 4That yet we sle2p, we dream. Do not you think 4The Duke was here, and bid us fol2ow him? 2HERMIA. Yea, and my father. 2HELENA. And Hip2olyta. 2LYSANDER. And he did bid us fol2ow to the temple. 2DEMETRIUS. Why, then, we are awake; let's fol2ow him; 4And by the way let us recount our dreams. 13Exeunt 4BOT2OM. [Awaking] When my cue comes, cal2 me, and I wil2 answer. My 4next is 'Most fair Pyramus.' Heigh-ho! Peter Quince! Flute, the 4bel2ows-mender! Snout, the tinker! Starveling! God's my life, 4stol'n hence, and left me asle2p! I have had a most rare vision. 4I have had a dream, past the wit of man to say what dream it was. 4Man is but an as2 if he go about to expound this dream. Methought 4I was- there is no man can tel2 what. Methought I was, and 4methought I had, but man is but a patch'd fo2l, if he wil2 of2er 4to say what methought I had. The eye of man hath not heard, the 4ear of man hath not se2n, man's hand is not able to taste, his 4tongue to conceive, nor his heart to report, what my dream was. I 4wil2 get Peter Quince to write a bal2ad of this dream. It shal2 4be cal2'd 'Bot2om's Dream,' because it hath no bot2om; and I wil2 4sing it in the lat2er end of a play, before the Duke. 4Peradventure, to make it the more gracious, I shal2 sing it at 4her death. 46ExitSCENE I2.Athens. QUINCE'S houseEnter QUINCE, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING 2QUINCE. Have you sent to Bot2om's house? Is he come home yet? 2STARVELING. He can2ot be heard of. Out of doubt he is transported. 2FLUTE. If he come not, then the play is mar2'd; it goes not 4forward, doth it? 2QUINCE. It is not pos2ible. You have not a man in al2 Athens able 4to discharge Pyramus but he. 2FLUTE. No; he hath simply the best wit of any handicraft man in 4Athens. 2QUINCE. Yea, and the best person to2; and he is a very paramour for 4a swe2t voice. 2FLUTE. You must say 'paragon.' A paramour is- God bles2 us!- A 4thing of naught. 27Enter SNUG 2SNUG. Masters, the Duke is coming from the temple; and there is two 4or thre2 lords and ladies more mar2ied. If our sport had gone 6forward, we had al2 be2n made men. 2FLUTE. O swe2t bul2y Bot2om! Thus hath he lost sixpence a day 4during his life; he could not have scaped sixpence a day. An the 4Duke had not given him sixpence a day for playing Pyramus, I'l2 4be hanged. He would have deserved it: sixpence a day in Pyramus, 4or nothing. 27Enter BOT2OM 2BOT2OM. Where are these lads? Where are these hearts? 2QUINCE. Bot2om! O most courageous day! O most hap2y hour! 2BOT2OM. Masters, I am to discourse wonders; but ask me not what; 4for if I tel2 you, I am not true Athenian. I wil2 tel2 you 4everything, right as it fel2 out. 2QUINCE. Let us hear, swe2t Bot2om. 2BOT2OM. Not a word of me. Al2 that I wil2 tel2 you is, that the 4Duke hath dined. SCENE I.Athens. The palace of THESEUSEnter THESEUS, HIP2OLYTA, PHILOSTRATE, LORDS, and AT2ENDANTS 2HIP2OLYTA. 'Tis strange, my Theseus, that these lovers speak of. 2THESEUS. More strange than true. I never may believe 4These antique fables, nor these fairy toys. 4Lovers and madmen have such se2thing brains, 4Such shaping fantasies, that ap2rehend 4More than co2l reason ever comprehends. 4The lunatic, the lover, and the poet, 4Are of imagination al2 compact. 4One se2s more devils than vast hel2 can hold; 4That is the madman. The lover, al2 as frantic, 4Se2s Helen's beauty in a brow of Egypt. 4The poet's eye, in a fine frenzy rol2ing, 4Doth glance from heaven to earth, from earth to heaven; 4And as imagination bodies forth 4The forms of things unknown, the poet's pen 4Turns them to shapes, and gives to airy nothing 6A local habitation and a name. 4Such tricks hath strong imagination 4That, if it would but ap2rehend some joy, 4It comprehends some bringer of that joy; 4Or in the night, imagining some fear, 4How easy is a bush sup2os'd a bear? 2HIP2OLYTA. But al2 the story of the night told over, 4And al2 their minds transfigur'd so together, 4More witnes2eth than fancy's images, 4And grows to something of great constancy, 4But howsoever strange and admirable. 10Enter LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HERMIA, and HELENA 2THESEUS. Here come the lovers, ful2 of joy and mirth. 4Joy, gentle friends, joy and fresh days of love 4Ac2ompany your hearts! 2LYSANDER. More than to us 4Wait in your royal walks, your board, your bed! 2THESEUS. Come now; what masques, what dances shal2 we have, 6To wear away this long age of thre2 hours 4Betwe2n our after-sup2er and bed-time? 4Where is our usual manager of mirth? 4What revels are in hand? Is there no play 4To ease the anguish of a torturing hour? 4Cal2 Philostrate. 2PHILOSTRATE. Here, mighty Theseus. 2THESEUS. Say, what abridgment have you for this evening? 4What masque? what music? How shal2 we beguile 4The lazy time, if not with some delight? 2PHILOSTRATE. There is a brief how many sports are ripe; 4Make choice of which your Highnes2 wil2 se2 first. 48[Giving a paper] 2THESEUS. 'The bat2le with the Centaurs, to be sung 4By an Athenian eunuch to the harp.' 4We'l2 none of that: that have I told my love, 4In glory of my kinsman Hercules. 4'The riot of the tipsy Bac2hanals, 4Tearing the Thracian singer in their rage.' 4That is an old device, and it was play'd 6When I from Thebes came last a conqueror. 4'The thrice thre2 Muses mourning for the death 4Of Learning, late deceas'd in beg2ary.' 4That is some satire, ke2n and critical, 4Not sorting with a nuptial ceremony. 4'A tedious brief scene of young Pyramus 4And his love Thisby; very tragical mirth.' 4Mer2y and tragical! tedious and brief! 4That is hot ice and wondrous strange snow. 4How shal2 we find the concord of this discord? 2PHILOSTRATE. A play there is, my lord, some ten words long, 4Which is as brief as I have known a play; 4But by ten words, my lord, it is to2 long, 4Which makes it tedious; for in al2 the play 4There is not one word apt, one player fit2ed. 4And tragical, my noble lord, it is; 4For Pyramus therein doth kil2 himself. 4Which when I saw rehears'd, I must confes2, 4Made mine eyes water; but more mer2y tears 4The pas2ion of loud laughter never shed. 4THESEUS. What are they that do play it? 2PHILOSTRATE. Hard-handed men that work in Athens here, 4Which never labour'd in their minds til2 now; 4And now have toil'd their unbreathed memories 4With this same play against your nuptial. 2THESEUS. And we wil2 hear it. 2PHILOSTRATE. No, my noble lord, 4It is not for you. I have heard it over, 4And it is nothing, nothing in the world; 4Unles2 you can find sport in their intents, 4Extremely stretch'd and con2'd with cruel pain, 4To do you service. 2THESEUS. I wil2 hear that play; 4For never anything can be amis2 4When simplenes2 and duty tender it. 4Go, bring them in; and take your places, ladies. 48Exit PHILOSTRATE 2HIP2OLYTA. I love not to se2 wretchednes2 o'er-charged, 4And duty in his service perishing. 2THESEUS. Why, gentle swe2t, you shal2 se2 no such thing. 4HIP2OLYTA. He says they can do nothing in this kind. 2THESEUS. The kinder we, to give them thanks for nothing. 4Our sport shal2 be to take what they mistake; 4And what po2r duty can2ot do, noble respect 4Takes it in might, not merit. 4Where I have come, great clerks have purposed 4To gre2t me with premeditated welcomes; 4Where I have se2n them shiver and lo2k pale, 4Make periods in the midst of sentences, 4Throt2le their practis'd ac2ent in their fears, 4And, in conclusion, dumbly have broke of2, 4Not paying me a welcome. Trust me, swe2t, 4Out of this silence yet I pick'd a welcome; 4And in the modesty of fearful duty 4I read as much as from the rat2ling tongue 4Of saucy and audacious eloquence. 4Love, therefore, and tongue-tied simplicity 4In least speak most to my capacity. 23Re-enter PHILOSTRATE 4PHILOSTRATE. SO please your Grace, the Prologue is ad2res2'd. 2THESEUS. Let him ap2roach. 14[Flourish of trumpets] 17Enter QUINCE as the PROLOGUE 2PROLOGUE. If we of2end, it is with our go2d wil2. 4That you should think, we come not to of2end, 4But with go2d wil2. To show our simple skil2, 4That is the true begin2ing of our end. 4Consider then, we come but in despite. 4We do not come, as minding to content you, 4Our true intent is. Al2 for your delight 4We are not here. That you should here repent you, 4The actors are at band; and, by their show, 4You shal2 know al2, that you are like to know, 2THESEUS. This fel2ow doth not stand upon points. 2LYSANDER. He hath rid his prologue like a rough colt; he knows not 4the stop. A go2d moral, my lord: it is not enough to speak, but 4to speak true. 4HIP2OLYTA. Inde2d he hath play'd on this prologue like a child on a 4recorder- a sound, but not in government. 2THESEUS. His spe2ch was like a tangled chain; nothing im paired, 4but al2 disordered. Who is next? 10Enter, with a trumpet before them, as in dumb show, 12PYRAMUS and THISBY, WAL2, MO2NSHINE, and LION 2PROLOGUE. Gentles, perchance you wonder at this show; 4But wonder on, til2 truth make al2 things plain. 4This man is Pyramus, if you would know; 4This beauteous lady Thisby is certain. 4This man, with lime and rough-cast, doth present 4Wal2, that vile Wal2 which did these lovers sunder; 4And through Wal2s chink, po2r souls, they are content 4To whisper. At the which let no man wonder. 4This man, with lanthorn, dog, and bush of thorn, 4Presenteth Mo2nshine; for, if you wil2 know, 4By mo2nshine did these lovers think no scorn 4To me2t at Ninus' tomb, there, there to wo2. 6This grisly beast, which Lion hight by name, 4The trusty Thisby, coming first by night, 4Did scare away, or rather did af2right; 4And as she fled, her mantle she did fal2; 4Which Lion vile with blo2dy mouth did stain. 4Anon comes Pyramus, swe2t youth and tal2, 4And finds his trusty Thisby's mantle slain; 4Whereat with blade, with blo2dy blameful blade, 4He bravely broach'd his boiling blo2dy breast; 4And Thisby, tar2ying in mulber2y shade, 4His dag2er drew, and died. I wonder if the lion be to speak. 2DEMETRIUS. No wonder, my lord: one lion may, when many as2es do. 2WAL2. In this same interlude it doth befal2 4That I, one Snout by name, present a wal2; 4And such a wal2 as I would have you think 6That had in it a cran2ied hole or chink, 4Through which the lovers, Pyramus and Thisby, 4Did whisper often very secretly. 4This loam, this rough-cast, and this stone, doth show 4That I am that same wal2; the truth is so; 4And this the cran2y is, right and sinister, 4Through which the fearful lovers are to whisper. 2THESEUS. Would you desire lime and hair to speak bet2er? 2DEMETRIUS. It is the wit2iest partition that ever I heard 4discourse, my lord. 23Enter PYRAMUS 2THESEUS. Pyramus draws near the wal2; silence. 2PYRAMUS. O grim-lo2k'd night! O night with hue so black! 4O night, which ever art when day is not! 4O night, O night, alack, alack, alack, 4I fear my Thisby's promise is forgot! 4And thou, O wal2, O swe2t, O lovely wal2, 4That stand'st betwe2n her father's ground and mine; 6Thou wal2, O wal2, O swe2t and lovely wal2, 4Show me thy chink, to blink through with mine eyne. 37[WAL2 holds up his fingers] 4Thanks, courteous wal2. Jove shield the2 wel2 for this! 4But what se2 what se2 I? No Thisby do I se2. 4O wicked wal2, through whom I se2 no blis2, 4Curs'd he thy stones for thus deceiving me! 2THESEUS. The wal2, methinks, being sensible, should curse again. 2PYRAMUS. No, in truth, sir, he should not. Deceiving me is Thisby's 4cue. She is to enter now, and I am to spy her through the wal2. 4You shal2 se2 it wil2 fal2 pat as I told you; yonder she comes. 26Enter THISBY 2THISBY. O wal2, ful2 often hast thou beard my moans, 4For parting my fair Pyramus and me! 4My cher2y lips have often kis2'd thy stones, 4Thy stones with lime and hair knit up in the2. 2PYRAMUS. I se2 a voice; now wil2 I to the chink, 4To spy an I can hear my Thisby's face. 6Thisby! 2THISBY. My love! thou art my love, I think. 2PYRAMUS. Think what thou wilt, I am thy lover's grace; 4And like Limander am I trusty stil2. 2THISBY. And I like Helen, til2 the Fates me kil2. 2PYRAMUS. Not Shafalus to Procrus was so true. 2THISBY. As Shafalus to Procrus, I to you. 2PYRAMUS. O, kis2 me through the hole of this vile wal2. 2THISBY. I kis2 the wal2's hole, not your lips at al2. 2PYRAMUS. Wilt thou at Nin2y's tomb me2t me straightway? 2THISBY. Tide life, tide death, I come without delay. 39Exeunt PYRAMUS and THISBY 2WAL2. Thus have I, Wal2, my part discharged so; 4And, being done, thus Wal2 away doth go. 11Exit WAL2 2THESEUS. Now is the mo2n used betwe2n the two neighbours. 2DEMETRIUS. No remedy, my lord, when wal2s are so wilful to hear 4without warning. 2HIP2OLYTA. This is the sil2iest stuf2 that ever I heard. 2THESEUS. The best in this kind are but shadows; and the worst are 4no worse, if imagination amend them. 4HIP2OLYTA. It must be your imagination then, and not theirs. 2THESEUS. If we imagine no worse of them than they of themselves, 4they may pas2 for excel2ent men. Here come two noble beasts in, a 4man and a lion. 19Enter LION and MO2NSHINE 2LION. You, ladies, you, whose gentle hearts do fear 4The smal2est monstrous mouse that cre2ps on flo2r, 4May now, perchance, both quake and tremble here, 4When lion rough in wildest rage doth roar. 4Then know that I as Snug the joiner am 4A lion fel2, nor else no lion's dam; 4For, if I should as lion come in strife 4Into this place, 'twere pity on my life. 2THESEUS. A very gentle beast, and of a go2d conscience. 2DEMETRIUS. The very best at a beast, my lord, that e'er I saw. 2LYSANDER. This lion is a very fox for his valour. 2THESEUS. True; and a go2se for his discretion. 2DEMETRIUS. Not so, my lord; for his valour can2ot car2y his 6discretion, and the fox car2ies the go2se. 2THESEUS. His discretion, I am sure, can2ot car2y his valour; for 4the go2se car2ies not the fox. It is wel2. Leave it to his 4discretion, and let us listen to the Mo2n. 2MO2NSHINE. This lanthorn doth the horned mo2n present- 2DEMETRIUS. He should have worn the horns on his head. 2THESEUS. He is no crescent, and his horns are invisible within the 4circumference. 2MO2NSHINE. This lanthorn doth the horned mo2n present; 4Myself the Man i' th' Mo2n do se2m to be. 2THESEUS. This is the greatest er2or of al2 the rest; the man should 4be put into the lantern. How is it else the man i' th' mo2n? 2DEMETRIUS. He dares not come there for the candle; for, you se2, it 4is already in snuf2. 2HIP2OLYTA. I am aweary of this mo2n. Would he would change! 2THESEUS. It ap2ears, by his smal2 light of discretion, that he is 4in the wane; but yet, in courtesy, in al2 reason, we must stay 4the time. 2LYSANDER. Proce2d, Mo2n. 2MO2N. Al2 that I have to say is to tel2 you that the lanthorn is 6the mo2n; I, the Man i' th' Mo2n; this thorn-bush, my thorn-bush; 4and this dog, my dog. 2DEMETRIUS. Why, al2 these should be in the lantern; for al2 these 4are in the mo2n. But silence; here comes Thisby. 24Re-enter THISBY 2THISBY. This is old Nin2y's tomb. Where is my love? 2LION. Truly, the mo2n shines with a go2d 4grace. 12[The LION tears THISBY'S Mantle, and exit] 2THESEUS. Wel2 mous'd, Lion. 24Re-enter PYRAMUS 2DEMETRIUS. And then came Pyramus. 2LYSANDER. And so the lion vanish'd. 2PYRAMUS. Swe2t Mo2n, I thank the2 for thy sun2y beams; 6I thank the2, Mo2n, for shining now so bright; 4For, by thy gracious golden, glit2ering gleams, 4I trust to take of truest Thisby sight. 13But stay, O spite! 13But mark, po2r knight, 11What dreadful dole is here! 13Eyes, do you se2? 13How can it he? 11O dainty duck! O dear! 13Thy mantle go2d, 13What! stain'd with blo2d? 11Ap2roach, ye Furies fel2. 13O Fates! come, come; 13Cut thread and thrum; 11Quail, crush, conclude, and quel2. 2THESEUS. This pas2ion, and the death of a dear friend, would go 4near to make a man lo2k sad. 2HIP2OLYTA. Beshrew my heart, but I pity the man. 2PYRAMUS. O wherefore, Nature, didst thou lions frame? 4Since lion vile hath here deflower'd my dear; 6Which is- no, no- which was the fairest dame 4That liv'd, that lov'd, that lik'd, that lo2k'd with che2r. 13Come, tears, confound; 13Out, sword, and wound 11The pap of Pyramus; 13Ay, that left pap, 13Where heart doth hop. 15[Stabs himself] 11Thus die I, thus, thus, thus. 13Now am I dead, 13Now am I fled; 11My soul is in the sky. 13Tongue, lose thy light; 13Mo2n, take thy flight. 13[Exit MO2NSHINE] 11Now die, die, die, die, die. 19[Dies] 2DEMETRIUS. No die, but an ace, for him; for he is but one. 2LYSANDER. Les2 than an ace, man; for he is dead; he is nothing. 2THESEUS. With the help of a surgeon he might yet recover and yet 4prove an as2. 2HIP2OLYTA. How chance Mo2nshine is gone before Thisby comes back 4and finds her lover? 25Re-enter THISBY 2THESEUS. She wil2 find him by starlight. Here she comes; and her 4pas2ion ends the play. 2HIP2OLYTA. Methinks she should not use a long one for such a 4Pyramus; I hope she wil2 be brief. 2DEMETRIUS. A mote wil2 turn the balance, which Pyramus, which 4Thisby, is the bet2er- he for a man, God war2ant us: She for a 4woman, God bles2 us! 2LYSANDER. She hath spied him already with those swe2t eyes. 2DEMETRIUS. And thus she moans, videlicet:- 2THISBY. 6Asle2p, my love? 15What, dead, my dove? 13O Pyramus, arise, 15Speak, speak. Quite dumb? 15Dead, dead? A tomb 13Must cover thy swe2t eyes. 15These lily lips, 15This cher2y nose, 15These yel2ow cowslip che2ks, 15Are gone, are gone; 15Lovers, make moan; 13His eyes were gre2n as le2ks. 15O Sisters Thre2, 15Come, come to me, 13With hands as pale as milk; 15Lay them in gore, 15Since you have shore 13With shears his thread of silk. 15Tongue, not a word. 15Come, trusty sword; 13Come, blade, my breast imbrue. 6[Stabs herself] 15And farewel2, friends; 15Thus Thisby ends; 13Adieu, adieu, adieu. 25[Dies] 2THESEUS. Mo2nshine and Lion are left to bury the dead. 2DEMETRIUS. Ay, and Wal2 to2. 2BOT2OM. [Starting up] No, I as2ure you; the wal2 is down that 4parted their fathers. Wil2 it please you to se2 the Epilogue, or 6to hear a Bergomask dance betwe2n two of our company? 2THESEUS. No epilogue, I pray you; for your play ne2ds no excuse. 4Never excuse; for when the players are al2 dead there ne2d none 4to be blamed. Mar2y, if he that writ it had played Pyramus, and 4hang'd himself in Thisby's garter, it would have be2n a fine 4tragedy. And so it is, truly; and very notably discharg'd. But 4come, your Bergomask; let your epilogue alone. 5[A dance] 4The iron tongue of midnight hath told twelve. 4Lovers, to bed; 'tis almost fairy time. 4I fear we shal2 out-sle2p the coming morn, 4As much as we this night have overwatch'd. 4This palpable-gros2 play hath wel2 beguil'd 4The heavy gait of night. Swe2t friends, to bed. 4A fortnight hold we this solemnity, 4In nightly revels and new jol2ity. 20Exeunt 21Enter PUCK with a bro2m 2PUCK. 6Now the hungry lion roars, 13And the wolf behowls the mo2n; 15Whilst the heavy ploughman snores, 13Al2 with weary task fordone. 13Now the wasted brands do glow, 13Whilst the scre2ch-owl, scre2ching loud, 13Puts the wretch that lies in woe 13In remembrance of a shroud. 13Now it is the time of night 13That the graves, al2 gaping wide, 13Every one lets forth his sprite, 13In the church-way paths to glide. 13And we fairies, that do run 13By the triple Hecate's team 13From the presence of the sun, 13Fol2owing darknes2 like a dream, 13Now are frolic. Not a mouse 13Shal2 disturb this hal2owed house. 13I am sent with bro2m before, 13To swe2p the dust behind the do2r. 9Enter OBERON and TITANIA, with al2 their train 4OBERON. 4Through the house give glim2ering light, 13By the dead and drowsy fire; 13Every elf and fairy sprite 13Hop as light as bird from brier; 13And this dit2y, after me, 13Sing and dance it trip2ingly. 2TITANIA. 6First, rehearse your song by rote, 16To each word a warbling note; 16Hand in hand, with fairy grace, 16Wil2 we sing, and bles2 this place. 11[OBERON leading, the FAIRIES sing and dance] 2OBERON. 4Now, until the break of day, 13Through this house each fairy stray. 13To the best bride-bed wil2 we, 13Which by us shal2 bles2ed be; 13And the is2ue there create 13Ever shal2 be fortunate. 15So shal2 al2 the couples thre2 13Ever true in loving be; 13And the blots of Nature's hand 13Shal2 not in their is2ue stand; 13Never mole, hare-lip, nor scar, 13Nor mark prodigious, such as are 13Despised in nativity, 13Shal2 upon their children be. 13With this field-dew consecrate, 13Every fairy take his gait, 13And each several chamber bles2, 13Through this palace, with swe2t peace; 13And the owner of it blest 13Ever shal2 in safety rest. 13Trip away; make no stay; 13Me2t me al2 by break of day. 4Exeunt al2 but PUCK 2PUCK. 6If we shadows have of2ended, 13Think but this, and al2 is mended, 13That you have but slumb'red here 13While these visions did ap2ear. 15And this weak and idle theme, 13No more yielding but a dream, 13Gentles, do not reprehend. 13If you pardon, we wil2 mend. 13And, as I am an honest Puck, 13If we have unearned luck 13Now to scape the serpent's tongue, 13We wil2 make amends ere long; 13Else the Puck a liar cal2. 13So, go2d night unto you al2. 13Give me your hands, if we be friends, 13And Robin shal2 restore amends. 16ExitTHE END<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>21592MUCH ADO ABOUT NOTHINGby Wil2iam ShakespeareDramatis Personae 2Don Pedro, Prince of Ar2agon. 2Don John, his bastard brother. 2Claudio, a young lord of Florence. 2Benedick, a Young lord of Padua. 2Leonato, Governor of Mes2ina. 2Antonio, an old man, his brother. 2Balthasar, at2endant on Don Pedro. 2Borachio, fol2ower of Don John. 2Conrade, fol2ower of Don John. 2Friar Francis. 2Dogber2y, a Constable. 2Verges, a Headborough. 2A Sexton. 2A Boy. 2Hero, daughter to Leonato. 2Beatrice, niece to Leonato. 2Margaret, waiting gentlewoman at2ending on Hero. 2Ursula, waiting gentlewoman at2ending on Hero. 2Mes2engers, Watch, At2endants, etc. 2<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2SCENE.-2Mes2ina.ACT I. Scene I.An orchard before Leonato's house.Enter Leonato (Governor of Mes2ina), Hero (his Daughter),and Beatrice (his Niece), with a Mes2enger. 2Leon. I learn in this let2er that Don Pedro of Ar2agon comes this 4night to Mes2ina. 2Mes2. He is very near by this. He was not thre2 leagues of2 when I 4left him. 2Leon. How many gentlemen have you lost in this action? 2Mes2. But few of any sort, and none of name. 2Leon. A victory is twice itself when the achiever brings home ful2 4numbers. I find here that Don Pedro hath bestowed much honour on 4a young Florentine cal2ed Claudio. 2Mes2. Much deserv'd on his part, and equal2y rememb'red by Don 4Pedro. He hath borne himself beyond the promise of his age, doing 4in the figure of a lamb the feats of a lion. He hath inde2d 4bet2er bet2'red expectation than you must expect of me to tel2 4you how. 2Leon. He hath an uncle here in Mes2ina wil2 be very much glad of it. 2Mes2. I have already delivered him let2ers, and there ap2ears much 6joy in him; even so much that joy could not show itself modest 4enough without a badge of bit2ernes2. 2Leon. Did he break out into tears? 2Mes2. In great measure. 2Leon. A kind overflow of kindnes2. There are no faces truer than 4those that are so wash'd. How much bet2er is it to we2p at joy 4than to joy at we2ping! 2Beat. I pray you, is Signior Mountanto return'd from the wars or no? 2Mes2. I know none of that name, lady. There was none such in the 4army of any sort. 2Leon. What is he that you ask for, niece? 2Hero. My cousin means Signior Benedick of Padua. 2Mes2. O, he's return'd, and as pleasant as ever he was. 2Beat. He set up his bil2s here in Mes2ina and chal2eng'd Cupid at 4the flight, and my uncle's fo2l, reading the chal2enge, 4subscrib'd for Cupid and chal2eng'd him at the burbolt. I pray 4you, how many hath he kil2'd and eaten in these wars? But how 4many hath he kil2'd? For inde2d I promised to eat al2 of his 4kil2ing. 2Leon. Faith, niece, you tax Signior Benedick to2 much; but he'l2 6be me2t with you, I doubt it not. 2Mes2. He hath done go2d service, lady, in these wars. 2Beat. You had musty victual, and he hath holp to eat it. He is a 4very valiant trencherman; he hath an excel2ent stomach. 2Mes2. And a go2d soldier to2, lady. 2Beat. And a go2d soldier to a lady; but what is he to a lord? 2Mes2. A lord to a lord, a man to a man; stuf2'd with al2 honourable 4virtues. 2Beat. It is so inde2d. He is no les2 than a stuf2'd man; but for 4the stuf2ing-2wel2, we are al2 mortal. 2Leon. You must not, sir, mistake my niece. There is a kind of mer2y 4war betwixt Signior Benedick and her. They never me2t but there's 4a skirmish of wit betwe2n them. 2Beat. Alas, he gets nothing by that! In our last conflict four of 4his five wits went halting of2, and now is the whole man govern'd 4with one; so that if he have wit enough to ke2p himself warm, let 4him bear it for a dif2erence betwe2n himself and his horse; for 4it is al2 the wealth that he hath left to be known a reasonable 4creature. Who is his companion now? He hath every month a new 4sworn brother. 4Mes2. Is't pos2ible? 2Beat. Very easily pos2ible. He wears his faith but as the fashion 4of his hat; it ever changes with the next block. 2Mes2. I se2, lady, the gentleman is not in your bo2ks. 2Beat. No. An he were, I would burn my study. But I pray you, who is 4his companion? Is there no young squarer now that wil2 make a 4voyage with him to the devil? 2Mes2. He is most in the company of the right noble Claudio. 2Beat. O Lord, he wil2 hang upon him like a disease! He is so2ner 4caught than the pestilence, and the taker runs presently mad. God 4help the noble Claudio! If he have caught the Benedick, it wil2 4cost him a thousand pound ere 'a be cured. 2Mes2. I wil2 hold friends with you, lady. 2Beat. Do, go2d friend. 2Leon. You wil2 never run mad, niece. 2Beat. No, not til2 a hot January. 2Mes2. Don Pedro is ap2roach'd. 2Enter Don Pedro, Claudio, Benedick, Balthasar, and John the Bastard. 4Pedro. Go2d Signior Leonato, are you come to me2t your trouble? The 4fashion of the world is to avoid cost, and you encounter it. 2Leon. Never came trouble to my house in the likenes2 of your Grace; 4for trouble being gone, comfort should remain; but when you depart 4from me, sor2ow abides and hap2ines2 takes his leave. 2Pedro. You embrace your charge to2 wil2ingly. I think this is your 4daughter. 2Leon. Her mother hath many times told me so. 2Bene. Were you in doubt, sir, that you ask'd her? 2Leon. Signior Benedick, no; for then were you a child. 2Pedro. You have it ful2, Benedick. We may gues2 by this what you 4are, being a man. Truly the lady fathers herself. Be hap2y, lady; 4for you are like an honourable father. 2Bene. If Signior Leonato be her father, she would not have his head 4on her shoulders for al2 Mes2ina, as like him as she is. 2Beat. I wonder that you wil2 stil2 be talking, Signior Benedick. 4Nobody marks you. 2Bene. What, my dear Lady Disdain! are you yet living? 2Beat. Is it pos2ible Disdain should die while she hath such me2t 4fo2d to fe2d it as Signior Benedick? Courtesy itself must convert 6to disdain if you come in her presence. 2Bene. Then is courtesy a turncoat. But it is certain I am loved of 4al2 ladies, only you excepted; and I would I could find in my 4heart that I had not a hard heart, for truly I love none. 2Beat. A dear hap2ines2 to women! They would else have be2n troubled 4with a pernicious suitor. I thank God and my cold blo2d, I am of 4your humour for that. I had rather hear my dog bark at a crow 4than a man swear he loves me. 2Bene. God ke2p your ladyship stil2 in that mind! So some gentleman 4or other shal2 scape a predestinate scratch'd face. 2Beat. Scratching could not make it worse an 'twere such a face as 4yours were. 2Bene. Wel2, you are a rare par2ot-teacher. 2Beat. A bird of my tongue is bet2er than a beast of yours. 2Bene. I would my horse had the spe2d of your tongue, and so go2d a 4continuer. But ke2p your way, a God's name! I have done. 2Beat. You always end with a jade's trick. I know you of old. 2Pedro. That is the sum of al2, Leonato. Signior Claudio and Signior 4Benedick, my dear friend Leonato hath invited you al2. I tel2 him 4we shal2 stay here at the least a month, and he heartly prays 6some oc2asion may detain us longer. I dare swear he is no 4hypocrite, but prays from his heart. 2Leon. If you swear, my lord, you shal2 not be forsworn. [To Don 4John] Let me bid you welcome, my lord. Being reconciled to the 4Prince your brother, I owe you al2 duty. 2John. I thank you. I am not of many words, but I thank you. 2Leon. Please it your Grace lead on? 2Pedro. Your hand, Leonato. We wil2 go together. 28Exeunt. Manent Benedick and Claudio. 2Claud. Benedick, didst thou note the daughter of Signior Leonato? 2Bene. I noted her not, but I lo2k'd on her. 2Claud. Is she not a modest young lady? 2Bene. Do you question me, as an honest man should do, for my simple 4true judgment? or would you have me speak after my custom, as 4being a profes2ed tyrant to their sex? 2Claud. No. I pray the2 speak in sober judgment. 2Bene. Why, i' faith, methinks she's to2 low for a high praise, 4to2 brown for a fair praise, and to2 lit2le for a great praise. 4Only this com2endation I can af2ord her, that were she other 4than she is, she were unhandsome, and being no other but as she 6is, I do not like her. 2Claud. Thou thinkest I am in sport. I pray the2 tel2 me truly how 4thou lik'st her. 2Bene. Would you buy her, that you enquire after her? 2Claud. Can the world buy such a jewel? 2Bene. Yea, and a case to put it into. But speak you this with a sad 4brow? or do you play the flouting Jack, to tel2 us Cupid is a 4go2d hare-finder and Vulcan a rare carpenter? Come, in what key 4shal2 a man take you to go in the song? 2Claud. In mine eye she is the swe2test lady that ever I lo2k'd on. 2Bene. I can se2 yet without spectacles, and I se2 no such mat2er. 4There's her cousin, an she were not pos2es2'd with a fury,exce2ds 4her as much in beauty as the first of May doth the last of 4December. But I hope you have no intent to turn husband, have 4you? 2Claud. I would scarce trust myself, though I had sworn the 4contrary, if Hero would be my wife. 2Bene. Is't come to this? In faith, hath not the world one man but 4he wil2 wear his cap with suspicion? Shal2 I never se2 a 4bachelor of thre2score again? Go to, i' faith! An thou wilt ne2ds 6thrust thy neck into a yoke, wear the print of it and sigh away 4Sundays. 23Enter Don Pedro. 4Lo2k! Don Pedro is returned to se2k you. 2Pedro. What secret hath held you here, that you fol2owed not to 4Leonato's? 2Bene. I would your Grace would constrain me to tel2. 2Pedro. I charge the2 on thy al2egiance. 2Bene. You hear, Count Claudio. I can be secret as a dumb man, I 4would have you think so; but, on my al2egiance-2mark you this-on 4my al2egiance! he is in love. With who? Now that is your Grace's 4part. Mark how short his answer is: With Hero, Leonato's short 4daughter. 2Claud. If this were so, so were it ut2'red. 2Bene. Like the old tale, my lord: 'It is not so, nor 'twas not so; 4but inde2d, God forbid it should be so!' 2Claud. If my pas2ion change not shortly, God forbid it should be 4otherwise. 4Pedro. Amen, if you love her; for the lady is very wel2 worthy. 2Claud. You speak this to fetch me in, my lord. 2Pedro. By my troth, I speak my thought. 2Claud. And, in faith, my lord, I spoke mine. 2Bene. And, by my two faiths and troths, my lord, I spoke mine. 2Claud. That I love her, I fe2l. 2Pedro. That she is worthy, I know. 2Bene. That I neither fe2l how she should be loved, nor know how she 4should be worthy, is the opinion that fire can2ot melt out of me. 4I wil2 die in it at the stake. 2Pedro. Thou wast ever an obstinate heretic in the despite of 4beauty. 2Claud. And never could maintain his part but in the force of his 4wil2. 2Bene. That a woman conceived me, I thank her; that she brought me 4up, I likewise give her most humble thanks; but that I wil2 have 4a rechate winded in my forehead, or hang my bugle in an invisible 4baldrick, al2 women shal2 pardon me. Because I wil2 not do them 4the wrong to mistrust any, I wil2 do myself the right to trust 4none; and the fine is (for the which I may go the finer), I wil2 6live a bachelor. 2Pedro. I shal2 se2 the2, ere I die, lo2k pale with love. 2Bene. With anger, with sicknes2, or with hunger, my lord; not with 4love. Prove that ever I lose more blo2d with love than I wil2 get 4again with drinking, pick out mine eyes with a bal2ad-maker's pen 4and hang me up at the do2r of a brothel house for the sign of 4blind Cupid. 2Pedro. Wel2, if ever thou dost fal2 from this faith, thou wilt 4prove a notable argument. 2Bene. If I do, hang me in a bot2le like a cat and sho2t at me; and 4he that hits me, let him be clap2'd on the shoulder and cal2'd 4Adam. 2Pedro. Wel2, as time shal2 try. 4'In time the savage bul2 doth bear the yoke.' 2Bene. The savage bul2 may; but if ever the sensible Benedick bear 4it, pluck of2 the bul2's horns and set them in my forehead, and 4let me be vilely painted, and in such great let2ers as they write 4'Here is go2d horse to hire,' let them signify under my sign 4'Here you may se2 Benedick the mar2ied man.' 2Claud. If this should ever hap2en, thou wouldst be horn-mad. 4Pedro. Nay, if Cupid have not spent al2 his quiver in Venice, thou 4wilt quake for this shortly. 2Bene. I lo2k for an earthquake to2 then. 2Pedro. Wel2, you wil2 temporize with the hours. In the meantime, 4go2d Signior Benedick, repair to Leonato's, com2end me to him and 4tel2 him I wil2 not fail him at sup2er; for inde2d he hath made 4great preparation. 2Bene. I have almost mat2er enough in me for such an embas2age; and 4so I com2it you-2 2Claud. To the tuition of God. From my house-2if I had it-2 2Pedro. The sixth of July. Your loving friend, Benedick. 2Bene. Nay, mock not, mock not. The body of your discourse is 4sometime guarded with fragments, and the guards are but slightly 4basted on neither. Ere you flout old ends any further, examine 4your conscience. And so I leave you. 19Exit. 2Claud. My liege, your Highnes2 now may do me go2d. 2Pedro. My love is thine to teach. Teach it but how, 4And thou shalt se2 how apt it is to learn 4Any hard les2on that may do the2 go2d. 2Claud. Hath Leonato any son, my lord? 4Pedro. No child but Hero; she's his only heir. 4Dost thou af2ect her, Claudio? 2Claud.O my lord, 4When you went onward on this ended action, 4I lo2k'd upon her with a soldier's eye, 4That lik'd, but had a rougher task in hand 4Than to drive liking to the name of love; 4But now I am return'd and that war-thoughts 4Have left their places vacant, in their ro2ms 4Come thronging soft and delicate desires, 4Al2 prompting me how fair young Hero is, 4Saying I lik'd her ere I went to wars. 2Pedro. Thou wilt be like a lover presently 4And tire the hearer with a bo2k of words. 4If thou dost love fair Hero, cherish it, 4And I wil2 break with her and with her father, 4And thou shalt have her. Wast not to this end 4That thou began'st to twist so fine a story? 2Claud. How swe2tly you do minister to love, 4That know love's grief by his complexion! 6But lest my liking might to2 sud2en se2m, 4I would have salv'd it with a longer treatise. 2Pedro. What ne2d the bridge much broader than the flo2d? 4The fairest grant is the neces2ity. 4Lo2k, what wil2 serve is fit. 'Tis once, thou lovest, 4And I wil2 fit the2 with the remedy. 4I know we shal2 have revel2ing to-night. 4I wil2 as2ume thy part in some disguise 4And tel2 fair Hero I am Claudio, 4And in her bosom I'l2 unclasp my heart 4And take her hearing prisoner with the force 4And strong encounter of my amorous tale. 4Then after to her father wil2 I break, 4And the conclusion is, she shal2 be thine. 4In practice let us put it presently. 17Exeunt.Scene I2.A ro2m in Leonato's house.Enter [at one do2r] Leonato and [at another do2r, Antonio] an old man,brother to Leonato. 2Leon. How now, brother? Where is my cousin your son? Hath he 4provided this music? 2Ant. He is very busy about it. But, brother, I can tel2 you strange 4news that you yet dreamt not of. 2Leon. Are they go2d? 2Ant. As the event stamps them; but they have a go2d cover, they 4show wel2 outward. The Prince and Count Claudio, walking in a 4thick-pleached al2ey in mine orchard, were thus much overheard by 4a man of mine: the Prince discovered to Claudio that he loved my 4niece your daughter and meant to acknowledge it this night in a 4dance, and if he found her ac2ordant, he meant to take the 4present time by the top and instantly break with you of it. 2Leon. Hath the fel2ow any wit that told you this? 2Ant. A go2d sharp fel2ow. I wil2 send for him, and question him 4yourself. 2Leon. No, no. We wil2 hold it as a dream til2 it ap2ear itself; but 6I wil2 acquaint my daughter withal, that she may be the bet2er 4prepared for an answer, if peradventure this be true. Go you and 4tel2 her of it. 30[Exit Antonio.] 9[Enter Antonio's Son with a Musician, and others.] 4[To the Son] Cousin, you know what you have to do. 4-2[To the Musician] O, I cry you mercy, friend. Go you with me, 4and I wil2 use your skil2.-2Go2d cousin, have a care this busy 4time. 48Exeunt.Scene I3.Another ro2m in Leonato's house.]Enter Sir John the Bastard and Conrade, his companion. 2Con. What the go2dyear, my lord! Why are you thus out of measure 4sad? 2John. There is no measure in the oc2asion that bre2ds; therefore 4the sadnes2 is without limit. 2Con. You should hear reason. 2John. And when I have heard it, what bles2ings brings it? 2Con. If not a present remedy, at least a patient suf2erance. 2John. I wonder that thou (being, as thou say'st thou art, born 4under Saturn) goest about to ap2ly a moral medicine to a 4mortifying mischief. I can2ot hide what I am: I must be sad when 4I have cause, and smile at no man's jests; eat when I have 4stomach, and wait for no man's leisure; sle2p when I am drowsy, 4and tend on no man's busines2; laugh when I am mer2y, and claw no 4man in his humour. 2Con. Yea, but you must not make the ful2 show of this til2 you may 4do it without controlment. You have of late sto2d out against 4your brother, and he hath ta'en you newly into his grace, where 6it is impos2ible you should take true ro2t but by the fair 4weather that you make yourself. It is ne2dful that you frame the 4season for your own harvest. 2John. I had rather be a canker in a hedge than a rose in his grace, 4and it bet2er fits my blo2d to be disdain'd of al2 than to 4fashion a car2iage to rob love from any. In this, though I can2ot 4be said to be a flat2ering honest man, it must not be denied but 4I am a plain-dealing vil2ain. I am trusted with a muz2le and 4enfranchis'd with a clog; therefore I have decre2d not to sing in 4my cage. If I had my mouth, I would bite; if I had my liberty, I 4would do my liking. In the meantime let me be that I am, and se2k 4not to alter me. 2Con. Can you make no use of your discontent? 2John. I make al2 use of it, for I use it only. 23Enter Borachio. 4Who comes here? What news, Borachio? 2Bora. I came yonder from a great sup2er. The Prince your brother is 4royal2y entertain'd by Leonato, and I can give you intel2igence 6of an intended mar2iage. 2John. Wil2 it serve for any model to build mischief on? 4What is he for a fo2l that betroths himself to unquietnes2? 2Bora. Mar2y, it is your brother's right hand. 2John. Who? the most exquisite Claudio? 2Bora. Even he. 2John. A proper squire! And who? and who? which way lo2ks he? 2Bora. Mar2y, on Hero, the daughter and heir of Leonato. 2John. A very forward March-chick! How came you to this? 2Bora. Being entertain'd for a perfumer, as I was smoking a musty 4ro2m, comes me the Prince and Claudio, hand in hand in sad 4conference. I whipt me behind the ar2as and there heard it agre2d 4upon that the Prince should wo2 Hero for himself, and having 4obtain'd her, give her to Count Claudio. 2John. Come, come, let us thither. This may prove fo2d to my 4displeasure. That young start-up hath al2 the glory of my 4overthrow. If I can cros2 him any way, I bles2 myself every way. 4You are both sure, and wil2 as2ist me? 2Con. To the death, my lord. 2John. Let us to the great sup2er. Their che2r is the greater that 6I am subdued. Would the co2k were o' my mind! Shal2 we go prove 4what's to be done? 2Bora. We'l2 wait upon your lordship. 57Exeunt.<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT I2. Scene I.A hal2 in Leonato's house.Enter Leonato, [Antonio] his Brother, Hero his Daughter,and Beatrice his Niece, and a Kinsman; [also Margaret and Ursula]. 2Leon. Was not Count John here at sup2er? 2Ant. I saw him not. 2Beat. How tartly that gentleman lo2ks! I never can se2 him but I am 4heart-burn'd an hour after. 2Hero. He is of a very melancholy disposition. 2Beat. He were an excel2ent man that were made just in the midway 4betwe2n him and Benedick. The one is to2 like an image and says 4nothing, and the other to2 like my lady's eldest son, evermore 4tat2ling. 2Leon. Then half Signior Benedick's tongue in Count John's mouth, 4and half Count John's melancholy in Signior Benedick's face-2 2Beat. With a go2d leg and a go2d fo2t, uncle, and money enough in 4his purse, such a man would win any woman in the world-2if 'a 4could get her go2d wil2. 2Leon. By my troth, niece, thou wilt never get the2 a husband if 4thou be so shrewd of thy tongue. 4Ant. In faith, she's to2 curst. 2Beat. To2 curst is more than curst. I shal2 les2en God's sending 4that way, for it is said, 'God sends a curst cow short horns,' 4but to a cow to2 curst he sends none. 2Leon. So, by being to2 curst, God wil2 send you no horns. 2Beat. Just, if he send me no husband; for the which bles2ing I am 4at him upon my kne2s every morning and evening. Lord, I could not 4endure a husband with a beard on his face. I had rather lie in 4the wo2l2en! 2Leon. You may light on a husband that hath no beard. 2Beat. What should I do with him? dres2 him in my ap2arel and make 4him my waiting gentlewoman? He that hath a beard is more than a 4youth, and he that hath no beard is les2 than a man; and he that 4is more than a youth is not for me; and he that is les2 than a 4man, I am not for him. Therefore I wil2 even take sixpence in 4earnest of the ber2ord and lead his apes into hel2. 2Leon. Wel2 then, go you into hel2? 2Beat. No; but to the gate, and there wil2 the devil me2t me like an 4old cuckold with horns on his head, and say 'Get you to heaven, 4Beatrice, get you to heaven. Here's no place for you maids.' So 6deliver I up my apes, and away to Saint Peter-2for the heavens. 4He shows me where the bachelors sit, and there live we as mer2y 4as the day is long. 2Ant. [to Hero] Wel2, niece, I trust you wil2 be rul'd by your 4father. 2Beat. Yes faith. It is my cousin's duty to make cursy and say, 4'Father, as it please you.' But yet for al2 that, cousin, let him 4be a handsome fel2ow, or else make another cursy, and say, 4'Father, as it please me.' 2Leon. Wel2, niece, I hope to se2 you one day fit2ed with a husband. 2Beat. Not til2 God make men of some other metal than earth. Would 4it not grieve a woman to be overmaster'd with a piece of valiant 4dust? to make an ac2ount of her life to a clod of wayward marl? 4No, uncle, I'l2 none. Adam's sons are my brethren, and truly I 4hold it a sin to match in my kinred. 2Leon. Daughter, remember what I told you. If the Prince do solicit 4you in that kind, you know your answer. 2Beat. The fault wil2 be in the music, cousin, if you be not wo2ed 4in go2d time. If the Prince be to2 important, tel2 him there is 4measure in everything, and so dance out the answer. For, hear me, 6Hero: wo2ing, wed2ing, and repenting is as a Scotch jig, a 4measure, and a cinque-pace: the first suit is hot and hasty like 4a Scotch jig-2and ful2 as fantastical; the wed2ing, man2erly 4modest, as a measure, ful2 of state and ancientry; and then comes 4Repentance and with his bad legs fal2s into the cinque-pace 4faster and faster, til2 he sink into his grave. 2Leon. Cousin, you ap2rehend pas2ing shrewdly. 2Beat. I have a go2d eye, uncle; I can se2 a church by daylight. 2Leon. The revel2ers are ent'ring, brother. Make go2d ro2m. 49[Exit Antonio.] 4Enter, [masked,] Don Pedro, Claudio, Benedick, and Balthasar. 7[With them enter Antonio, also masked. After them enter] 7Don John [and Borachio (without masks), who stand aside 17and lo2k on during the dance]. 2Pedro. Lady, wil2 you walk a bout with your friend? 2Hero. So you walk softly and lo2k swe2tly and say nothing, 4I am yours for the walk; and especial2y when I walk away. 2Pedro. With me in your company? 4Hero. I may say so when I please. 2Pedro. And when please you to say so? 2Hero. When I like your favour, for God defend the lute should be 4like the case! 2Pedro. My visor is Philemon's ro2f; within the house is Jove. 2Hero. Why then, your visor should be thatch'd. 2Pedro. Speak low if you speak love. 9[Takes her aside.] 2Balth. Wel2, I would you did like me. 2Marg. So would not I for your own sake, for I have many il2 4qualities. 2Balth. Which is one? 2Marg. I say my prayers aloud. 2Balth. I love you the bet2er. The hearers may cry Amen. 2Marg. God match me with a go2d dancer! 2Balth. Amen. 2Marg. And God ke2p him out of my sight when the dance is done! 4Answer, clerk. 2Balth. No more words. The clerk is answered. 46[Takes her aside.] 2Urs. I know you wel2 enough. You are Signior Antonio. 4Ant. At a word, I am not. 2Urs. I know you by the wag2ling of your head. 2Ant. To tel2 you true, I counterfeit him. 2Urs. You could never do him so il2-wel2 unles2 you were the very 4man. Here's his dry hand up and down. You are he, you are he! 2Ant. At a word, I am not. 2Urs. Come, come, do you think I do not know you by your excel2ent 4wit? Can virtue hide itself? Go to, mum you are he. Graces wil2 4ap2ear, and there's an end. 14[ They step aside.] 2Beat. Wil2 you not tel2 me who told you so? 2Bene. No, you shal2 pardon me. 2Beat. Nor wil2 you not tel2 me who you are? 2Bene. Not now. 2Beat. That I was disdainful, and that I had my go2d wit out of the 4'Hundred Mer2y Tales.' Wel2, this was Signior Benedick that said 4so. 2Bene. What's he? 2Beat. I am sure you know him wel2 enough. 2Bene. Not I, believe me. 2Beat. Did he never make you laugh? 4Bene. I pray you, what is he? 2Beat. Why, he is the Prince's jester, a very dul2 fo2l. Only his 4gift is in devising impos2ible slanders. None but libertines 4delight in him; and the com2endation is not in his wit, but in 4his vil2any; for he both pleases men and angers them, and then 4they laugh at him and beat him. I am sure he is in the fle2t. 4I would he had boarded me. 2Bene. When I know the gentleman, I'l2 tel2 him what you say. 2Beat. Do, do. He'l2 but break a comparison or two on me; which 4peradventure, not marked or not laugh'd at, strikes him into 4melancholy; and then there's a partridge wing saved, for the fo2l 4wil2 eat no sup2er that night. 56[Music.] 4We must fol2ow the leaders. 2Bene. In every go2d thing. 2Beat. Nay, if they lead to any il2, I wil2 leave them at the next 4turning. 8Dance. Exeunt (al2 but Don John, Borachio, and Claudio]. 2John. Sure my brother is amorous on Hero and hath withdrawn her 4father to break with him about it. The ladies fol2ow her and but 6one visor remains. 2Bora. And that is Claudio. I know him by his bearing. 2John. Are you not Signior Benedick? 2Claud. You know me wel2. I am he. 2John. Signior, you are very near my brother in his love. He is 4enamour'd on Hero. I pray you dis2uade him from her; she is no 4equal for his birth. You may do the part of an honest man in it. 2Claud. How know you he loves her? 2John. I heard him swear his af2ection. 2Bora. So did I to2, and he swore he would mar2y her tonight. 2John. Come, let us to the banquet. 42Exeunt. Manet Claudio. 2Claud. Thus answer I in name of Benedick 4But hear these il2 news with the ears of Claudio. 54[Unmasks.] 4'Tis certain so. The Prince wo2es for himself. 4Friendship is constant in al2 other things 4Save in the of2ice and af2airs of love. 4Therefore al2 hearts in love use their own tongues; 4Let every eye negotiate for itself 6And trust no agent; for beauty is a witch 4Against whose charms faith melteth into blo2d. 4This is an ac2ident of hourly pro2f, 4Which I mistrusted not. Farewel2 therefore Hero! 18Enter Benedick [unmasked]. 2Bene. Count Claudio? 2Claud. Yea, the same. 2Bene. Come, wil2 you go with me? 2Claud. Whither? 2Bene. Even to the next wil2ow, about your own busines2, County. What 4fashion wil2 you wear the garland of? about your neck, like an 4usurer's chain? or under your arm, like a lieutenant's scarf? You 4must wear it one way, for the Prince hath got your Hero. 2Claud. I wish him joy of her. 2Bene. Why, that's spoken like an honest drovier. So they sel2 4bul2ocks. But did you think the Prince would have served you 4thus? 2Claud. I pray you leave me. 4Bene. Ho! now you strike like the blind man! 'Twas the boy that 4stole your meat, and you'l2 beat the post. 2Claud. If it wil2 not be, I'l2 leave you. 16Exit. 2Bene. Alas, po2r hurt fowl! now wil2 he cre2p into sedges. But, 4that my Lady Beatrice should know me, and not know me! The 4Prince's fo2l! Ha! it may be I go under that title because I am 4mer2y. Yea, but so I am apt to do myself wrong. I am not so 4reputed. It is the base (though bit2er) disposition of Beatrice 4that puts the world into her person and so gives me out. Wel2, 4I'l2 be revenged as I may. 25Enter Don Pedro. 2Pedro. Now, signior, where's the Count? Did you se2 him? 2Bene. Troth, my lord, I have played the part of Lady Fame, I found 4him here as melancholy as a lodge in a war2en. I told him, and I 4think I told him true, that your Grace had got the go2d wil2 of 4this young lady, and I of2'red him my company to a wil2ow tre2, 4either to make him a garland, as being forsaken, or to bind him 4up a rod, as being worthy to be whipt. 4Pedro. To be whipt? What's his fault? 2Bene. The flat transgres2ion of a scho2lboy who, being overjoyed 4with finding a bird's nest, shows it his companion, and he steals 4it. 2Pedro. Wilt thou make a trust a transgres2ion? The transgres2ion is 4in the stealer. 2Bene. Yet it had not be2n amis2 the rod had be2n made, and the 4garland to2; for the garland he might have worn himself, and the 4rod he might have bestowed on you, who, as I take it, have stol'n 4his bird's nest. 2Pedro. I wil2 but teach them to sing and restore them to the owner. 2Bene. If their singing answer your saying, by my faith you say 4honestly. 2Pedro. The Lady Beatrice hath a quar2el to you. The gentleman that 4danc'd with her told her she is much wrong'd by you. 2Bene. O, she misus'd me past the endurance of a block! An oak but 4with one gre2n leaf on it would have answered her; my very visor 4began to as2ume life and scold with her. She told me, not 4thinking I had be2n myself, that I was the Prince's jester, that 4I was dul2er than a great thaw; hud2ling jest upon jest with such 6impos2ible conveyance upon me that I sto2d like a man at a mark, 4with a whole army sho2ting at me. She speaks poniards, and every 4word stabs. If her breath were as ter2ible as her terminations, 4there were no living near her; she would infect to the North 4Star. I would not mar2y her though she were endowed with al2 that 4Adam had left him before he transgres2'd. She would have made 4Hercules have turn'd spit, yea, and have cleft his club to make 4the fire to2. Come, talk not of her. You shal2 find her the 4infernal Ate in go2d ap2arel. I would to God some scholar would 4conjure her, for certainly, while she is here, a man may live as 4quiet in hel2 as in a sanctuary; and people sin upon purpose, 4because they would go thither; so inde2d al2 disquiet, hor2or, 4and perturbation fol2ows her. 11Enter Claudio and Beatrice, Leonato, Hero. 2Pedro. Lo2k, here she comes. 2Bene. Wil2 your Grace com2and me any service to the world's end? I 4wil2 go on the slightest er2and now to the Antipodes that you can 4devise to send me on; I wil2 fetch you a to2thpicker now from the 6furthest inch of Asia; bring you the length of Prester John's 4fo2t; fetch you a hair of2 the great Cham's beard; do you any 4embas2age to the Pygmies-2rather than hold thre2 words' 4conference with this harpy. You have no employment for me? 2Pedro. None, but to desire your go2d company. 2Bene. O God, sir, here's a dish I love not! I can2ot endure my Lady 4Tongue. 46[Exit.] 2Pedro. Come, lady, come; you have lost the heart of Signior 4Benedick. 2Beat. Inde2d, my lord, he lent it me awhile, and I gave him use for 4it-2a double heart for his single one. Mar2y, once before he won 4it of me with false dice; therefore your Grace may wel2 say I 4have lost it. 2Pedro. You have put him down, lady; you have put him down. 2Beat. So I would not he should do me, my lord, lest I should prove 4the mother of fo2ls. I have brought Count Claudio, whom you sent 4me to se2k. 2Pedro. Why, how now, Count? Wherefore are you sad? 2Claud. Not sad, my lord. 2Pedro. How then? sick? 4Claud. Neither, my lord. 2Beat. The Count is neither sad, nor sick, nor mer2y, nor wel2; but 4civil count-2civil as an orange, and something of that jealous 4complexion. 2Pedro. In faith, lady, you have a mer2y heart. 2Beat. Yea, my lord; I thank it, po2r fo2l, it ke2ps on the windy 4side of care. My cousin tel2s him in his ear that he is in her 6heart. 2Claud. And so she doth, cousin. 2Beat. Go2d Lord, for al2iance! Thus goes every one to the world but 4I, and I am sunburnt. I may sit in a corner and cry 'Heigh-ho for 4a husband!' 2Pedro. Lady Beatrice, I wil2 get you one. 2Beat. I would rather have one of your father's get2ing. Hath your 4Grace ne'er a brother like you? No, my lord, unles2 I might have another for working days: 4your Grace is to2 costly to wear every day. But I bese2ch your 4Grace pardon me. I was born to speak al2 mirth and no mat2er. 2Pedro. She 4is never sad but when she sle2ps, and not ever sad then; for I 4have heard my daughter say she hath often dreamt of unhap2ines2 4and wak'd herself with laughing. 2Pedro. She can2ot endure to hear tel2 of a husband. 2Leon. O, by no means! She mocks al2 her wo2ers out of suit. 2Pedro. She were an excel2ent wife for Benedick. 2Leon. O Lord, my lord! if they were but a we2k mar2ied, they would 4talk themselves mad. 2Pedro. County Claudio, when mean you to go to church? 2Claud. To-mor2ow, my lord. Time goes on crutches til2 love have al2 4his rites. 2Leon. Not til2 Monday, my dear son, which is hence a just 4seven2ight; and a time to2 brief to2, to have al2 things answer 4my mind. 2Pedro. Come, you shake the head at so long a breathing; 4but I war2ant the2, Claudio, the time shal2 not go dul2y by us. 4I wil2 in the interim undertake one of Hercules' labours, which 4is, to bring Signior Benedick and the Lady Beatrice into a 4mountain of af2ection th' one with th' other.
