I wil2 do any modest of2ice, my lord, to help my cousin to a 4go2d husband. 2Pedro. And Benedick is not the unhopeful2est husband that I know. 4Thus far can I praise him: he is of a noble strain, of ap2roved 4valour, and confirm'd honesty. I wil2 teach you how to humour 4your cousin, that she shal2 fal2 in love with Benedick; and I, 4[to Leonato and Claudio] with your two helps, wil2 so practise on 4Benedick that, in despite of his quick wit and his queasy 4stomach, he shal2 fal2 in love with Beatrice. If we can do this, 4Cupid is no longer an archer; his glory shal2 be ours, for we are 4the only love-gods. Go in with me, and I wil2 tel2 you my drift. 57Exeunt.Scene I2.A hal2 in Leonato's house.Enter [Don] John and Borachio. 2John. It is so. The Count Claudio shal2 mar2y the daughter of 4Leonato. 2Bora. Yea, my lord; but I can cros2 it. 2John. Any bar, any cros2, any impediment wil2 be med'cinable to me. 4I am sick in displeasure to him, and whatsoever comes athwart his 4af2ection ranges evenly with mine. How canst thou cros2 this 4mar2iage? 2Bora. Not honestly, my lord, but so covertly that no dishonesty 4shal2 ap2ear in me. 2John. Show me briefly how. 2Bora. I think I told your lordship, a year since, how much I am in 4the favour of Margaret, the waiting gentlewoman to Hero. 2John. I remember. 2Bora. I can, at any unseasonable instant of the night, ap2oint her 4to lo2k out at her lady's chamber window. 2John. What life is in that to be the death of this mar2iage? 2Bora. The poison of that lies in you to temper. Go you to the 6Prince your brother; spare not to tel2 him that he hath wronged 4his honour in mar2ying the renowned Claudio (whose estimation do 4you mightily hold up) to a contaminated stale, such a one as 4Hero. 2John. What pro2f shal2 I make of that? 2Bora. Pro2f enough to misuse the Prince, to vex Claudio, to undo 4Hero, and kil2 Leonato. Lo2k you for any other is2ue? 2John. Only to despite them I wil2 endeavour anything. 2Bora. Go then; find me a me2t hour to draw Don Pedro and the Count 4Claudio alone; tel2 them that you know that Hero loves me; intend 4a kind of zeal both to the Prince and Claudio, as-2in love of 4your brother's honour, who hath made this match, and his friend's 4reputation, who is thus like to be cozen'd with the semblance of 4a maid-2that you have discover'd thus. They wil2 scarcely believe 4this without trial. Of2er them instances; which shal2 bear no 4les2 likeliho2d than to se2 me at her chamber window, hear me 4cal2 Margaret Hero, hear Margaret term me Claudio; and bring them 4to se2 this the very night before the intended wed2ing (for in 4the meantime I wil2 so fashion the mat2er that Hero shal2 be 4absent) and there shal2 ap2ear such se2ming truth of Hero's 6disloyalty that jealousy shal2 be cal2'd as2urance and al2 the 4preparation overthrown. 2John. Grow this to what adverse is2ue it can, I wil2 put it in 4practice. Be cun2ing in the working this, and thy fe2 is a 4thousand ducats. 2Bora. Be you constant in the ac2usation, and my cun2ing shal2 not 4shame me. 2John. I wil2 presently go learn their day of mar2iage. 57Exeunt.Scene I3.Leonato's orchard.Enter Benedick alone. 2Bene. Boy! 20[Enter Boy.] 2Boy. Signior? 2Bene. In my chamber window lies a bo2k. Bring it hither to me in 4the orchard. 2Boy. I am here already, sir. 2Bene. I know that, but I would have the2 hence and here again. 4(Exit Boy.) I do much wonder that one man, se2ing how much 4another man is a fo2l when he dedicates his behaviours to love, 4wil2, after he hath laugh'd at such shal2ow fol2ies in others, 4become the argument of his own scorn by fal2ing in love; and such 4a man is Claudio. I have known when there was no music with him 4but the drum and the fife; and now had he rather hear the tabor 4and the pipe. I have known when he would have walk'd ten mile 4afo2t to se2 a go2d armour; and now wil2 he lie ten nights awake 6carving the fashion of a new doublet. He was wont to speak plain 4and to the purpose, like an honest man and a soldier; and now is 4he turn'd orthography; his words are a very fantastical banquet-2 4just so many strange dishes. May I be so converted and se2 with 4these eyes? I can2ot tel2; I think not. I wil2 not be sworn but 4love may transform me to an oyster; but I'l2 take my oath on it, 4til2 he have made an oyster of me he shal2 never make me such a 4fo2l. One woman is fair, yet I am wel2; another is wise, yet I am 4wel2; another virtuous, yet I am wel2; but til2 al2 graces be in 4one woman, one woman shal2 not come in my grace. Rich she shal2 4be, that's certain; wise, or I'l2 none; virtuous, or I'l2 never 4cheapen her; fair, or I'l2 never lo2k on her; mild, or come not 4near me; noble, or not I for an angel; of go2d discourse, an 4excel2ent musician, and her hair shal2 be of what colour it 4please God. Ha, the Prince and Monsieur Love! I wil2 hide me in 4the arbour. 41[Hides.] 14Enter Don Pedro, Leonato, Claudio. 22Music [within]. 4Pedro. Come, shal2 we hear this music? 2Claud. Yea, my go2d lord. How stil2 the evening is, 4As hush'd on purpose to grace harmony! 2Pedro. Se2 you where Benedick hath hid himself? 2Claud. O, very wel2, my lord. The music ended, 4We'l2 fit the kid-fox with a pen2yworth. 19Enter Balthasar with Music. 2Pedro. Come, Balthasar, we'l2 hear that song again. 2Balth. O, go2d my lord, tax not so bad a voice 4To slander music any more than once. 2Pedro. It is the witnes2 stil2 of excel2ency 4To put a strange face on his own perfection. 4I pray the2 sing, and let me wo2 no more. 2Balth. Because you talk of wo2ing, I wil2 sing, 4Since many a wo2er doth com2ence his suit 4To her he thinks not worthy, yet he wo2es, 4Yet wil2 he swear he loves. 2Pedro. Nay, pray the2 come; 6Or if thou wilt hold longer argument, 4Do it in notes. 2Balth. Note this before my notes: 4There's not a note of mine that's worth the noting. 2Pedro. Why, these are very crotchets that he speaks! 4Note notes, forso2th, and nothing! 18[Music.] 2Bene. [aside] Now divine air! Now is his soul ravish'd! Is it not 4strange that she2p's guts should hale souls out of men's bodies? 4Wel2, a horn for my money, when al2's done. 46[Balthasar sings.] 22The Song. 8Sigh no more, ladies, sigh no more! 10Men were deceivers ever, 8One fo2t in sea, and one on shore; 10To one thing constant never. 12Then sigh not so, 12But let them go, 10And be you blithe and bon2y, 8Converting al2 your sounds of woe 12Into Hey non2y, non2y. 8Sing no more dit2ies, sing no moe, 10Of dumps so dul2 and heavy! 8The fraud of men was ever so, 10Since sum2er first was leavy. 12Then sigh not so, &c. 2Pedro. By my troth, a go2d song. 2Balth. And an il2 singer, my lord. 2Pedro. Ha, no, no, faith! Thou sing'st wel2 enough for a shift. 2Bene. [aside] An he had be2n a dog that should have howl'd thus, 4they would have hang'd him; and I pray God his bad voice bode no 4mischief. I had as live have heard the night raven, come what 4plague could have come after it. 2Pedro. Yea, mar2y. Dost thou hear, Balthasar? I pray the2 get us 4some excel2ent music; for to-mor2ow night we would have it at the 4Lady Hero's chamber window. 2Balth. The best I can, my lord. 2Pedro. Do so. Farewel2. 34Exit Balthasar [with Musicians]. 4Come hither, Leonato. What was it you told me of to-day? that 4your niece Beatrice was in love with Signior Benedick? 2Claud. O, ay!-[Aside to Pedro] Stalk on, stalk on; the fowl sits. 4-2I did never think that lady would have loved any man. 2Leon. No, nor I neither; but most wonderful that she should so dote 4on Signior Benedick, whom she hath in al2 outward behaviours 4se2m'd ever to abhor. 2Bene. [aside] Is't pos2ible? Sits the wind in that corner? 2Leon. By my troth, my lord, I can2ot tel2 what to think of it, but 4that she loves him with an enraged af2ection. It is past the 4infinite of thought. 2Pedro. May be she doth but counterfeit. 2Claud. Faith, like enough. 2Leon. O God, counterfeit? There was never counterfeit of pas2ion 4came so near the life of pas2ion as she discovers it. 2Pedro. Why, what ef2ects of pas2ion shows she? 2Claud. [aside] Bait the ho2k wel2! This fish wil2 bite. 2Leon. What ef2ects, my lord? She wil2 sit you-2you heard my 4daughter tel2 you how. 4Claud. She did inde2d. 2Pedro. How, how, I pray you? You amaze me. I would have thought her 4spirit had be2n invincible against al2 as2aults of af2ection. 2Leon. I would have sworn it had, my lord-2especial2y against 4Benedick. 2Bene. [aside] I should think this a gul2 but that the white-bearded 4fel2ow speaks it. Knavery can2ot, sure, hide himself in such 4reverence. 2Claud. [aside] He hath ta'en th' infection. Hold it up. 2Pedro. Hath she made her af2ection known to Benedick? 2Leon. No, and swears she never wil2. That's her torment. 2Claud. 'Tis true inde2d. So your daughter says. 'Shal2 I,' says 4she, 'that have so oft encount'red him with scorn, write to him 4that I love him?'" 2Leon. This says she now when she is begin2ing to write to him; for 4she'l2 be up twenty times a night, and there wil2 she sit in her 4smock til2 she have writ a she2t of paper. My daughter tel2s us 4al2. 2Claud. Now you talk of a she2t of paper, I remember a pret2y jest 4your daughter told us of. 4Leon. O, when she had writ it, and was reading it over, she found 4'Benedick' and 'Beatrice' betwe2n the she2t? 2Claud. That. 2Leon. O, she tore the let2er into a thousand halfpence, rail'd at 4herself that she should be so im2odest to write to one that she 4knew would flout her. 'I measure him,' says she, 'by my own 4spirit; for I should flout him if he writ to me. Yea, though I 4love him, I should.' 2Claud. Then down upon her kne2s she fal2s, we2ps, sobs, beats her 4heart, tears her hair, prays, curses-2'O swe2t Benedick! God give 4me patience!' 2Leon. She doth inde2d; my daughter says so. And the ecstasy hath so 4much overborne her that my daughter is sometime afeard she wil2 4do a desperate outrage to herself. It is very true. 2Pedro. It were go2d that Benedick knew of it by some other, if she 4wil2 not discover it. 2Claud. To what end? He would make but a sport of it and torment the 4po2r lady worse. 2Pedro. An he should, it were an alms to hang him! She's an 4excel2ent swe2t lady, and (out of al2 suspicion) she is virtuous. 4Claud. And she is exce2ding wise. 2Pedro. In everything but in loving Benedick. 2Leon. O, my lord, wisdom and blo2d combating in so tender a body, 4we have ten pro2fs to one that blo2d hath the victory. I am sor2y 4for her, as I have just cause, being her uncle and her guardian. 2Pedro. I would she had bestowed this dotage on me. I would have 4daf2'd al2 other respects and made her half myself. I pray you 4tel2 Benedick of it and hear what 'a wil2 say. 2Leon. Were it go2d, think you? 2Claud. Hero thinks surely she wil2 die; for she says she wil2 die 4if he love her not, and she wil2 die ere she make her love known, 4and she wil2 die, if he wo2 her, rather than she wil2 bate one 4breath of her ac2ustomed cros2nes2. 2Pedro. She doth wel2. If she should make tender of her love, 'tis 4very pos2ible he'l2 scorn it; for the man (as you know al2) hath 4a contemptible spirit. 2Claud. He is a very proper man. 2Pedro. He hath inde2d a go2d outward hap2ines2. 2Claud. Before God! and in my mind, very wise. 2Pedro. He doth inde2d show some sparks that are like wit. 4Claud. And I take him to be valiant. 2Pedro. As Hector, I as2ure you; and in the managing of quar2els you 4may say he is wise, for either he avoids them with great 4discretion, or undertakes them with a most Christianlike fear. 2Leon. If he do fear God, 'a must neces2arily ke2p peace. If he 4break the peace, he ought to enter into a quar2el with fear and 4trembling. 2Pedro. And so wil2 he do; for the man doth fear God, howsoever it 4se2ms not in him by some large jests he wil2 make. Wel2, I am 4sor2y for your niece. Shal2 we go se2k Benedick and tel2 him of 4her love? 2Claud. Never tel2 him, my lord. Let her wear it out with go2d 4counsel. 2Leon. Nay, that's impos2ible; she may wear her heart out first. 2Pedro. Wel2, we wil2 hear further of it by your daughter. Let it 4co2l the while. I love Benedick wel2, and I could wish he would 4modestly examine himself to se2 how much he is unworthy so go2d a 4lady. 2Leon. My lord, wil2 you .walk? Din2er is ready. 47[They walk away.] 4Claud. If he dote on her upon this, I wil2 never trust my 4expectation. 2Pedro. Let there be the same net spread for her, and that must your 4daughter and her gentlewomen car2y. The sport wil2 be, when they 4hold one an opinion of another's dotage, and no such mat2er. 4That's the scene that I would se2, which wil2 be merely a dumb 4show. Let us send her to cal2 him in to din2er. 23Exeunt [Don Pedro, Claudio, and Leonato]. 16[Benedick advances from the arbour.] 2Bene. This can be no trick. The conference was sadly borne; they 4have the truth of this from Hero; they se2m to pity the lady. 4It se2ms her af2ections have their ful2 bent. Love me? Why, it 4must be requited. I hear how I am censur'd. They say I wil2 bear 4myself proudly if I perceive the love come from her. They say to2 4that she wil2 rather die than give any sign of af2ection. I did 4never think to mar2y. I must not se2m proud. Hap2y are they that 4hear their detractions and can put them to mending. They say the 4lady is fair-2'tis a truth, I can bear them witnes2; and virtuous 6-2'tis so, I can2ot reprove it; and wise, but for loving me-2by 4my troth, it is no ad2ition to her wit, nor no great argument of 4her fol2y, for I wil2 be hor2ibly in love with her. I may chance 4have some od2 quirks and remnants of wit broken on me because I 4have railed so long against mar2iage. But doth not the ap2etite 4alters? A man loves the meat in his youth that he can2ot endure 4in his age. Shal2 quips and sentences and these paper bul2ets of 4the brain awe a man from the care2r of his humour? No, the world 4must be peopled. When I said I would die a bachelor, I did not 4think I should live til2 I were mar2ied. 17Enter Beatrice. 4Here comes Beatrice. By this day, she's a fair lady! I do spy 4some marks of love in her. 2Beat. Against my wil2 I am sent to bid You come in to din2er. 2Bene. Fair Beatrice, I thank you for your pains. 2Beat. I to2k no more pains for those thanks than you take pains to 4thank me. If it had be2n painful, I would not have come. 2Bene. You take pleasure then in the mes2age? 4Beat. Yea, just so much as you may take upon a knives point, and 4choke a daw withal. You have no stomach, signior. Fare you wel2.Exit. 2Bene. Ha! 'Against my wil2 I am sent to bid you come in to din2er.' 4There's a double meaning in that. 'I to2k no more pains for those 4thanks than you to2k pains to thank me.' That's as much as to 4say, 'Any pains that I take for you is as easy as thanks.' If I 4do not take pity of her, I am a vil2ain; if I do not love her, I 4am a Jew. I wil2 go get her picture. 19Exit.<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT I3. Scene I.Leonato's orchard.Enter Hero and two Gentlewomen, Margaret and Ursula. 2Hero. Go2d Margaret, run the2 to the parlour. 4There shalt thou find my cousin Beatrice 4Proposing with the Prince and Claudio. 4Whisper her ear and tel2 her, I and Ursley 4Walk in the orchard, and our whole discourse 4Is al2 of her. Say that thou overheard'st us; 4And bid her steal into the pleached bower, 4Where honeysuckles, ripened by the sun, 4Forbid the sun to enter-2like favourites, 4Made proud by princes, that advance their pride 4Against that power that bred it. There wil2 she hide her 4To listen our propose. This is thy of2ice. 4Bear the2 wel2 in it and leave us alone. 2Marg. I'l2 make her come, I war2ant you, presently. 4[Exit.] 2Hero. Now, Ursula, when Beatrice doth come, 4As we do trace this al2ey up and down, 4Our talk must only be of Benedick. 6When I do name him, let it be thy part 4To praise him more than ever man did merit. 4My talk to the2 must be how Benedick 4Is sick in love with Beatrice. Of this mat2er 4Is lit2le Cupid's crafty ar2ow made, 4That only wounds by hearsay. 19[Enter Beatrice.] 4Now begin; 4For lo2k where Beatrice like a lapwing runs 4Close by the ground, to hear our conference. 15[Beatrice hides in the arbour]. 2Urs. The pleasant'st angling is to se2 the fish 4Cut with her golden oars the silver stream 4And gre2dily devour the treacherous bait. 4So angle we for Beatrice, who even now 4Is couched in the wo2dbine coverture. 6Fear you not my part of the dialogue. 2Hero. Then go we near her, that her ear lose nothing 4Of the false swe2t bait that we lay for it. 37[They ap2roach the arbour.] 4No, truly, Ursula, she is to2 disdainful. 4I know her spirits are as coy and wild 4As hag2ards of the rock. 2Urs. But are you sure 4That Benedick loves Beatrice so entirely? 2Hero. So says the Prince, and my new-trothed lord. 2Urs. And did they bid you tel2 her of it, madam? 2Hero. They did entreat me to acquaint her of it; 4But I persuaded them, if they lov'd Benedick, 4To wish him wrestle with af2ection 4And never to let Beatrice know of it. 2Urs. Why did you so? Doth not the gentleman 4Deserve as ful2, as fortunate a bed 4As ever Beatrice shal2 couch upon? 2Hero. O god of love! I know he doth deserve 4As much as may be yielded to a man: 6But Nature never fram'd a woman's heart 4Of prouder stuf2 than that of Beatrice. 4Disdain and scorn ride sparkling in her eyes, 4Misprizing what they lo2k on; and her wit 4Values itself so highly that to her 4Al2 mat2er else se2ms weak. She can2ot love, 4Nor take no shape nor project of af2ection, 4She is so self-endeared. 2Urs. Sure I think so; 4And therefore certainly it were not go2d 4She knew his love, lest she'l2 make sport at it. 2Hero. Why, you speak truth. I never yet saw man, 4How wise, how noble, young, how rarely featur'd, 4But she would spel2 him backward. If fair-fac'd, 4She would swear the gentleman should be her sister; 4If black, why, Nature, drawing of an antic, 4Made a foul blot; if tal2, a lance il2-headed; 4If low, an agate very vilely cut; 4If speaking, why, a vane blown with al2 winds; 4If silent, why, a block moved with none. 6So turns she every man the wrong side out 4And never gives to truth and virtue that 4Which simplenes2 and merit purchaseth. 2Urs. Sure, sure, such carping is not com2endable. 2Hero. No, not to be so od2, and from al2 fashions, 4As Beatrice is, can2ot be com2endable. 4But who dare tel2 her so? If I should speak, 4She would mock me into air; O, she would laugh me 4Out of myself, pres2 me to death with wit! 4Therefore let Benedick, like cover'd fire, 4Consume away in sighs, waste inwardly. 4It were a bet2er death than die with mocks, 4Which is as bad as die with tickling. 2Urs. Yet tel2 her of it. Hear what she wil2 say. 2Hero. No; rather I wil2 go to Benedick 4And counsel him to fight against his pas2ion. 4And truly, I'l2 devise some honest slanders 4To stain my cousin with. One doth not know 4How much an il2 word may empoison liking. 2Urs. O, do not do your cousin such a wrong! 6She can2ot be so much without true judgment 4(Having so swift and excel2ent a wit 4As she is priz'd to have) as to refuse 4So rare a gentleman as Signior Benedick. 2Hero. He is the only man of Italy, 4Always excepted my dear Claudio. 2Urs. I pray you be not angry with me, madam, 4Speaking my fancy: Signior Benedick, 4For shape, for bearing, argument, and valour, 4Goes foremost in report through Italy. 2Hero. Inde2d he hath an excel2ent go2d name. 2Urs. His excel2ence did earn it ere he had it. 4When are you mar2ied, madam? 2Hero. Why, every day to-mor2ow! Come, go in. 4I'l2 show the2 some at2ires, and have thy counsel 4Which is the best to furnish me to-mor2ow. 47[They walk away.] 2Urs. She's lim'd, I war2ant you! We have caught her, madam. 2Hero. If it prove so, then loving goes by haps; 4Some Cupid kil2s with ar2ows, some with traps. 41Exeunt [Hero and Ursula]. 4[Beatrice advances from the arbour.] 2Beat. What fire is in mine ears? Can this be true? 4Stand I condemn'd for pride and scorn so much? 4Contempt, farewel2! and maiden pride, adieu! 4No glory lives behind the back of such. 4And, Benedick, love on; I wil2 requite the2, 4Taming my wild heart to thy loving hand. 4If thou dost love, my kindnes2 shal2 incite the2 4To bind our loves up in a holy band; 4For others say thou dost deserve, and I 4Believe it bet2er than reportingly. 20Exit.Scene I2.A ro2m in Leonato's house.Enter Don Pedro, Claudio, Benedick, and Leonato. 2Pedro. I do but stay til2 your mar2iage be consum2ate, and then go 4I toward Ar2agon. 2Claud. I'l2 bring you thither, my lord, if you'l2 vouchsafe me. 2Pedro. Nay, that would be as great a soil in the new glos2 of your 4mar2iage as to show a child his new coat and forbid him to wear 4it. I wil2 only be bold with Benedick for his company; for, from 4the crown of his head to the sole of his fo2t, he is al2 mirth. 4He hath twice or thrice cut Cupid's bowstring, and the lit2le 4hangman dare not sho2t at him. He hath a heart as sound as a 4bel2; and his tongue is the clap2er, for what his heart thinks, 4his tongue speaks. 2Bene. Gal2ants, I am not as I have be2n. 2Leon. So say I. Methinks you are sad2er. 2Claud. I hope he be in love. 2Pedro. Hang him, truant! There's no true drop of blo2d in him to be 4truly touch'd with love. If he be sad, he wants money. 2Bene. I have the to2thache. 4Pedro. Draw it. 2Bene. Hang it! 2Claud. You must hang it first and draw it afterwards. 2Pedro. What? sigh for the to2thache? 2Leon. Where is but a humour or a worm. 2Bene. Wel2, every one can master a grief but he that has it. 2Claud. Yet say I he is in love. 2Pedro. There is no ap2earance of fancy in him, unles2 it be a fancy 4that he hath to strange disguises; as to be a Dutchman to-day, a 4Frenchman to-mor2ow; or in the shape of two countries at once, as 4a German from the waist downward, al2 slops, and a Spaniard from 4the hip upward, no doublet. Unles2 he have a fancy to this 4fo2lery, as it ap2ears he hath, he is no fo2l for fancy, as you 4would have it ap2ear he is. 2Claud. If he be not in love with some woman, there is no believing 4old signs. 'A brushes his hat o' mornings. What should that bode? 2Pedro. Hath any man se2n him at the barber's? 2Claud. No, but the barber's man hath be2n se2n with him, and the 5old ornament of his che2k hath already stuf2'd ten2is bal2s. 2Leon. Inde2d he lo2ks younger than he did, by the los2 of a beard. 4Pedro. Nay, 'a rubs himself with civet. Can you smel2 him out by 4that? 2Claud. That's as much as to say, the swe2t youth's in love. 2Pedro. The greatest note of it is his melancholy. 2Claud. And when was he wont to wash his face? 2Pedro. Yea, or to paint himself? for the which I hear what they say 4of him. 2Claud. Nay, but his jesting spirit, which is new-crept into a 4lutestring, and now govern'd by stops. 2Pedro. Inde2d that tel2s a heavy tale for him. Conclude, conclude, 4he is in love. 2Claud. Nay, but I know who loves him. 2Pedro. That would I know to2. I war2ant, one that knows him not. 2Claud. Yes, and his il2 conditions; and in despite of al2, dies for 4him. 2Pedro. She shal2 be buried with her face upwards. 2Bene. Yet is this no charm for the to2thache. Old signior, walk 4aside with me. I have studied eight or nine wise words to speak 4to you, which these hob2y-horses must not hear. 34[Exeunt Benedick and Leonato.] 4Pedro. For my life, to break with him about Beatrice! 2Claud. 'Tis even so. Hero and Margaret have by this played their 4parts with Beatrice, and then the two bears wil2 not bite one 4another when they me2t. 17Enter John the Bastard. 2John. My lord and brother, God save you. 2Pedro. Go2d den, brother. 2John. If your leisure serv'd, I would speak with you. 2Pedro. In private? 2John. If it please you. Yet Count Claudio may hear, for what I 4would speak of concerns him. 2Pedro. What's the mat2er? 2John. [to Claudio] Means your lordship to be mar2ied tomor2ow? 2Pedro. You know he does. 2John. I know not that, when he knows what I know. 2Claud. If there be any impediment, I pray you discover it. 2John. You may think I love you not. Let that ap2ear hereafter, and 4aim bet2er at me by that I now wil2 manifest. For my brother, I 6think he holds you wel2 and in dearnes2 of heart hath holp to 4ef2ect your ensuing mar2iage-2surely suit il2 spent and labour 4il2 bestowed! 2Pedro. Why, what's the mat2er? 2John. I came hither to tel2 you, and, circumstances short'ned (for 4she has be2n to2 long a-talking of), the lady is disloyal. 2Claud. Who? Hero? 2John. Even she-2Leonato's Hero, your Hero, every man's Hero. 2Claud. Disloyal? 2John. The word is to2 go2d to paint out her wickednes2. I could say 4she were worse; think you of a worse title, and I wil2 fit her to 4it. Wonder not til2 further war2ant. Go but with me to-night, you 4shal2 se2 her chamber window ent'red, even the night before her 4wed2ing day. If you love her then, to-mor2ow wed her. But it 4would bet2er fit your honour to change your mind. 2Claud. May this be so? 2Pedro. I wil2 not think it. 2John. If you dare not trust that you se2, confes2 not that you 4know. If you wil2 fol2ow me, I wil2 show you enough; and when you 4have se2n more and heard more, proce2d ac2ordingly. 4Claud. If I se2 anything to-night why I should not mar2y her 4to-mor2ow, in the congregation where I should wed, there wil2 I 4shame her. 2Pedro. And, as I wo2ed for the2 to obtain her, I wil2 join with 4the2 to disgrace her. 2John. I wil2 disparage her no farther til2 you are my witnes2es. 4Bear it coldly but til2 midnight, and let the is2ue show itself. 2Pedro. O day untowardly turned! 2Claud. O mischief strangely thwarting! 2John. O plague right wel2 prevented! 4So wil2 you say when you have se2n the Sequel. 57Exeunt.Scene I3.A stre2t.Enter Dogber2y and his compartner [Verges], with the Watch. 2Dog. Are you go2d men and true? 2Verg. Yea, or else it were pity but they should suf2er salvation, 4body and soul. 2Dog. Nay, that were a punishment to2 go2d for them if they should 4have any al2egiance in them, being chosen for the Prince's watch. 2Verg. Wel2, give them their charge, neighbour Dogber2y. 2Dog. First, who think you the most desartles2 man to be constable? 21. Watch. Hugh Oatcake, sir, or George Seacoal; for they can write 4and read. 2Dog. Come hither, neighbour Seacoal. God hath bles2'd you with a 4go2d name. To be a wel2-favoured man is the gift of fortune, but 4to write and read comes by nature. 22. Watch. Both which, Master Constable-2 2Dog. You have. I knew it would be your answer. Wel2, for your 4favour, sir, why, give God thanks and make no boast of it; and 4for your writing and reading, let that ap2ear when there is no 4ne2d of such vanity. You are thought here to be the most 6senseles2 and fit man for the constable of the watch. Therefore 4bear you the lanthorn. This is your charge: you shal2 comprehend 4al2 vagrom men; you are to bid any man stand, in the Prince's 4name. 22. Watch. How if 'a wil2 not stand? 2Dog. Why then, take no note of him, but let him go, and presently 4cal2 the rest of the watch together and thank God you are rid of 4a knave. 2Verg. If he wil2 not stand when he is bid2en, he is none of the 4Prince's subjects. 2Dog. True, and they are to med2le with none but the Prince's 4subjects. You shal2 also make no noise in the stre2ts; for for 4the watch to bab2le and to talk is most tolerable, and not to be 4endured. 22. Watch. We wil2 rather sle2p than talk. We know what belongs to 4a watch. 2Dog. Why, you speak like an ancient and most quiet watchman, for I 4can2ot se2 how sle2ping should of2end. Only have a care that your 4bil2s be not stol'n. Wel2, you are to cal2 at al2 the alehouses 4and bid those that are drunk get them to bed. 42. Watch. How if they wil2 not? 2Dog. Why then, let them alone til2 they are sober. If they make you 4not then the bet2er answer, You may say they are not the men you 4to2k them for. 22. Watch. Wel2, sir. 2Dog. If you me2t a thief, you may suspect him, by virtue of your 4of2ice, to be no true man; and for such kind of men, the les2 you 4med2le or make with them, why, the more your honesty. 22. Watch. If we know him to be a thief, shal2 we not lay hands on 4him? 2Dog. Truly, by your of2ice you may; but I think they that touch 4pitch wil2 be defil'd. The most peaceable way for you, if you do 4take a thief, is to let him show himself what he is, and steal 4out of your company. 2Verg. You have be2n always cal2ed a merciful man, partner. 2Dog. Truly, I would not hang a dog by my wil2, much more a man who 4hath any honesty in him. 2Verg. If you hear a child cry in the night, you must cal2 to the 4nurse and bid her stil2 it. 22. Watch. How if the nurse be asle2p and wil2 not hear us? 4Dog. Why then, depart in peace and let the child wake her with 4crying; for the ewe that wil2 not hear her lamb when it baes wil2 4never answer a calf when he bleats. 2Verg. 'Tis very true. 2Dog. This is the end of the charge: you, constable, are to present 4the Prince's own person. If you me2t the Prince in the night, 4you may stay him. 2Verg. Nay, by'r lady, that I think 'a can2ot. 2Dog. Five shil2ings to one on't with any man that knows the 4statutes, he may stay him! Mar2y, not without the Prince be 4wil2ing; for inde2d the watch ought to of2end no man, and it is 4an of2ence to stay a man against his wil2. 2Verg. By'r lady, I think it be so. 2Dog. Ha, ah, ha! Wel2, masters, go2d night. An there be any mat2er 4of weight chances, cal2 up me. Ke2p your fel2ows' counsels and 4your own, and go2d night. Come, neighbour. 22. Watch. Wel2, masters, we hear our charge. Let us go sit here 4upon the church bench til2 two, and then al2 to bed. 2Dog. One word more, honest neighbours. I pray you watch about 4Signior Leonato's do2r; for the wed2ing being there tomor2ow, 6there is a great coil to-night. Adieu. Be vigitant, I bese2ch 4you. 27Exeunt [Dogber2y and Verges]. 21Enter Borachio and Conrade. 2Bora. What, Conrade! 22. Watch. [aside] Peace! stir not! 2Bora. Conrade, I say! 2Con. Here, man. I am at thy elbow. 2Bora. Mas2, and my elbow itch'd! I thought there would a scab 4fol2ow. 2Con. I wil2 owe the2 an answer for that; and now forward with thy 4tale. 2Bora. Stand the2 close then under this penthouse, for it driz2les 4rain, and I wil2, like a true drunkard, ut2er al2 to the2. 22. Watch. [aside] Some treason, masters. Yet stand close. 2Bora. Therefore know I have earned of Don John a thousand ducats. 2Con. Is it pos2ible that any vil2any should be so dear? 2Bora. Thou shouldst rather ask if it were pos2ible any vil2any 4should be so rich; for when rich vil2ains have ne2d of po2r ones, 6po2r ones may make what price they wil2. 2Con. I wonder at it. 2Bora. That shows thou art unconfirm'd. Thou knowest that the 4fashion of a doublet, or a hat, or a cloak, is nothing to a man. 2Con. Yes, it is ap2arel. 2Bora. I mean the fashion. 2Con. Yes, the fashion is the fashion. 2Bora. Tush! I may as wel2 say the fo2l's the fo2l. But se2st thou 4not what a deformed thief this fashion is? 22. Watch. [aside] I know that Deformed. 'A bas be2n a vile thief 4this seven year; 'a goes up and down like a gentleman. I remember 4his name. 2Bora. Didst thou not hear somebody? 2Con. No; 'twas the vane on the house. 2Bora. Se2st thou not, I say, what a deformed thief this fashion is? 4how gid2ily 'a turns about al2 the hot-blo2ds betwe2n fourte2n 4and five-and-thirty? sometimes fashioning them like Pharaoh's 4soldiers in the re2chy painting, sometime like god Bel's priests 4in the old church window, sometime like the shaven Hercules in 4the smirch'd worm-eaten tapestry, where his codpiece se2ms as 6mas2y as his club? 2Con. Al2 this I se2; and I se2 that the fashion wears out more 4ap2arel than the man. But art not thou thyself gid2y with the 4fashion to2, that thou hast shifted out of thy tale into tel2ing 4me of the fashion? 2Bora. Not so neither. But know that I have to-night wo2ed Margaret, 4the Lady Hero's gentlewoman, by the name of Hero. She leans me 4out at her mistres2' chamber window, bids me a thousand times 4go2d night-2I tel2 this tale vilely; I should first tel2 the2 how 4the Prince, Claudio and my master, planted and placed and 4pos2es2ed by my master Don John, saw afar of2 in the orchard this 4amiable encounter. 2Con. And thought they Margaret was Hero? 2Bora. Two of them did, the Prince and Claudio; but the devil my 4master knew she was Margaret; and partly by his oaths, which 4first pos2es2'd them, partly by the dark night, which did deceive 4them, but chiefly by my vil2any, which did confirm any slander 4that Don John had made, away went Claudio enrag'd; swore he would 4me2t her, as he was ap2ointed, next morning at the temple, and 4there, before the whole congregation, shame her with what he saw 6o'ernight and send her home again without a husband. 22. Watch. We charge you in the Prince's name stand! 21. Watch. Cal2 up the right Master Constable. We have here 4recover'd the most dangerous piece of lechery that ever was known 4in the com2onwealth. 22. Watch. And one Deformed is one of them. I know him; 'a wears a 4lock. 2Con. Masters, masters-2 21. Watch. You'l2 be made bring Deformed forth, I war2ant you. 2Con. Masters-2 22. Watch. Never speak, we charge you. Let us obey you to go with 4us. 2Bora. We are like to prove a go2dly com2odity, being taken up of 4these men's bil2s. 2Con. A com2odity in question, I war2ant you. Come, we'l2 obey you. 57Exeunt.Scene IV.A Ro2m in Leonato's house.Enter Hero, and Margaret and Ursula. 2Hero. Go2d Ursula, wake my cousin Beatrice and desire her to rise. 2Urs. I wil2, lady. 2Hero. And bid her come hither. 2Urs. Wel2. 45[Exit.] 2Marg. Troth, I think your other rebato were bet2er. 2Hero. No, pray the2, go2d Meg, I'l2 wear this. 2Marg. By my troth, 's not so go2d, and I war2ant your cousin wil2 4say so. 2Hero. My cousin's a fo2l, and thou art another. I'l2 wear none but 4this. 2Marg. I like the new tire within excel2ently, if the hair were a 4thought browner; and your gown's a most rare fashion, i' faith. 4I saw the Duches2 of Milan's gown that they praise so. 2Hero. O, that exce2ds, they say. 2Marg. By my troth, 's but a nightgown in respect of yours-2 4cloth-o'-gold and cuts, and lac'd with silver, set with pearls 4down sle2ves, side-sle2ves, and skirts, round underborne with 6a blush tinsel. But for a fine, quaint, graceful, and excel2ent 4fashion, yours is worth ten on't. 2Hero. God give me joy to wear it! for my heart is exce2ding heavy. 2Marg. 'Twil2 be heavier so2n by the weight of a man. 2Hero. Fie upon the2! art not ashamed? 2Marg. Of what, lady? of speaking honourably? Is not mar2iage 4honourable in a beg2ar? Is not your lord honourable without 4mar2iage? I think you would have me say, 'saving your reverence, 4a husband.' An bad thinking do not wrest true speaking, I'l2 4of2end nobody. Is there any harm in 'the heavier for a husband'? 4None, I think, an it be the right husband and the right wife. 4Otherwise 'tis light, and not heavy. Ask my Lady Beatrice else. 4Here she comes. 31Enter Beatrice. 2Hero. Go2d mor2ow, coz. 2Beat. Go2d mor2ow, swe2t Hero. 2Hero. Why, how now? Do you speak in the sick tune? 2Beat. I am out of al2 other tune, methinks. 4Marg. Clap's into 'Light o' love.' That goes without a burden. Do 4you sing it, and I'l2 dance it. 2Beat. Yea, 'Light o' love' with your he2ls! then, if your husband 4have stables enough, you'l2 se2 he shal2 lack no barnes. 2Marg. O il2egitimate construction! I scorn that with my he2ls. 2Beat. 'Tis almost five o'clock, cousin; 'tis time you were ready. 4By my troth, I am exce2ding il2. Hey-ho! 2Marg. For a hawk, a horse, or a husband? 2Beat. For the let2er that begins them al2, H. 2Marg. Wel2, an you be not turn'd Turk, there's no more sailing by 4the star. 2Beat. What means the fo2l, trow? 2Marg. Nothing I; but God send every one their heart's desire! 2Hero. These gloves the Count sent me, they are an excel2ent 4perfume. 2Beat. I am stuf2'd, cousin; I can2ot smel2. 2Marg. A maid, and stuf2'd! There's go2dly catching of cold. 2Beat. O, God help me! God help me! How long have you profes2'd 4ap2rehension? 2Marg. Ever since you left it. Doth not my wit become me rarely? 4Beat. It is not se2n enough. You should wear it in your cap. By my 4troth, I am sick. 2Marg. Get you some of this distil2'd cardu2s benedictus and lay it 4to your heart. It is the only thing for a qualm. 2Hero. There thou prick'st her with a thistle. 2Beat. Benedictus? why benedictus? You have some moral in this 4'benedictus.' 2Marg. Moral? No, by my troth, I have no moral meaning; I meant 4plain holy thistle. You may think perchance that I think you are 4in love. Nay, by'r lady, I am not such a fo2l to think what I 4list; nor I list not to think what I can; nor inde2d I can2ot 4think, if I would think my heart out of thinking, that you are in 4love, or that you wil2 be in love, or that you can be in love. 4Yet Benedick was such another, and now is he become a man. He 4swore he would never mar2y; and yet now in despite of his heart 4he eats his meat without grudging; and how you may be converted I 4know not, but methinks you lo2k with your eyes as other women do. 2Beat. What pace is this that thy tongue ke2ps? 2Marg. Not a false gal2op. 27Enter Ursula. 2Urs. Madam, withdraw. What would you with me, honest neighbour? 2Dog. Mar2y, sir, I would have some confidence with you that decerns 4you nearly. 2Leon. Brief, I pray you; for you se2 it is a busy time with me. 2Dog. Mar2y, this it is, sir. 2Verg. Yes, in truth it is, sir. 2Leon. What is it, my go2d friends? 2Dog. Go2dman Verges, sir, speaks a lit2le of2 the mat2er-2an old 4man, sir, and his wits are not so blunt as, God help, I would 4desire they were; but, in faith, honest as the skin betwe2n his 4brows. 2Verg. Yes, I thank God I am as honest as any man living that is an 4old man and no honester than I. 2Dog. Comparisons are odorous. Palabras, neighbour Verges. 2Leon. Neighbours, you are tedious. 2Dog. It pleases your worship to say so, but we are the po2r Duke's 6of2icers; but truly, for mine own part, if I were as tedious as a 4king, I could find in my heart to bestow it al2 of your worship. 2Leon. Al2 thy tediousnes2 on me, ah? 2Dog. Yea, in 'twere a thousand pound more than 'tis; for I hear as 4go2d exclamation on your worship as of any man in the city; and 4though I be but a po2r man, I am glad to hear it. 2Verg. And so am I. 2Leon. I would fain know what you have to say. 2Verg. Mar2y, sir, our watch to-night, excepting your worship's 4presence, ha' ta'en a couple of as ar2ant knaves as any in 4Mes2ina. 2Dog. A go2d old man, sir; he wil2 be talking. As they say, 'When 4the age is in, the wit is out.' God help us! it is a world to 4se2! Wel2 said, i' faith, neighbour Verges. Wel2, God's a go2d 4man. An two men ride of a horse, one must ride behind. An honest 4soul, i' faith, sir, by my troth he is, as ever broke bread; but 4God is to be worship2'd; al2 men are not alike, alas, go2d 4neighbour! 2Leon. Inde2d, neighbour, he comes to2 short of you. 2Dog. Gifts that God gives. 4Leon. I must leave you. 2Dog. One word, sir. Our watch, sir, have inde2d comprehended two 4aspicious persons, and we would have them this morning examined 4before your worship. 2Leon. Take their examination yourself and bring it me. I am now in 4great haste, as it may ap2ear unto you. 2Dog. It shal2 be suf2igance. 2Leon. Drink some wine ere you go. Fare you wel2. 23[Enter a Mes2enger.] 2Mes2. My lord, they stay for you to give your daughter to her 4husband. 2Leon. I'l2 wait upon them. I am ready. 33[Exeunt Leonato and Mes2enger.] 2Dog. We wil2 spare for no wit, I war2ant you. Here's that shal2 6drive some of them to a non-come. Scene I.A church.Enter Don Pedro, [John the] Bastard, Leonato, Friar [Francis], Claudio,Benedick, Hero, Beatrice, [and At2endants]. 2Leon. Come, Friar Francis, be brief. Only to the plain form of 4mar2iage, and you shal2 recount their particular duties 4afterwards. 2Friar. You come hither, my lord, to mar2y this lady? 2Claud. No. 2Leon. To be mar2ied to her. Friar, you come to mar2y her. 2Friar. Lady, you come hither to be mar2ied to this count? 2Hero. I do. 2Friar. If either of you know any inward impediment why you should 4not be conjoined, I charge you on your souls to ut2er it. 2Claud. Know you any, Hero? 2Hero. None, my lord. 2Friar. Know you any, Count? 2Leon. I dare make his answer-2none. 2Claud. O, what men dare do! what men may do! what men daily do, not 4knowing what they do! 4Bene. How now? interjections? Why then, some be of laughing, as, 4ah, ha, he! 2Claud. Stand the2 by, friar. Father, by your leave: 4Wil2 you with fre2 and unconstrained soul 4Give me this maid your daughter? 2Leon. As fre2ly, son, as God did give her me. 2Claud. And what have I to give you back whose worth 4May counterpoise this rich and precious gift? 2Pedro. Nothing, unles2 you render her again. 2Claud. Swe2t Prince, you learn me noble thankfulnes2. 4There, Leonato, take her back again. 4Give not this rot2en orange to your friend. 4She's but the sign and semblance of her honour. 4Behold how like a maid she blushes here! 4O, what authority and show of truth 4Can cun2ing sin cover itself withal! 4Comes not that blo2d as modest evidence 4To witnes2 simple virtue, Would you not swear, 4Al2 you that se2 her, that she were a maid 4By these exterior shows? But she is none: 6She knows the heat of a luxurious bed; 4Her blush is guiltines2, not modesty. 2Leon. What do you mean, my lord? 2Claud. Not to be mar2ied, 4Not to knit my soul to an ap2roved wanton. 2Leon. Dear my lord, if you, in your own pro2f, 4Have vanquish'd the resistance of her youth 4And made defeat of her virginity-2 2Claud. I know what you would say. If I have known her, 4You wil2 say she did embrace me as a husband, 4And so extenuate the forehand sin. 4No, Leonato, 4I never tempted her with word to2 large, 4But, as a brother to his sister, show'd 4Bashful sincerity and comely love. 2Hero. And se2m'd I ever otherwise to you? 2Claud. Out on the se2ming! I wil2 write against it. 4You se2m to me as Dian in her orb, 4As chaste as is the bud ere it be blown; 4But you are more intemperate in your blo2d 6Than Venus, or those pamp'red animals 4That rage in savage sensuality. 2Hero. Is my lord wel2 that he doth speak so wide? 2Leon. Swe2t Prince, why speak not you? 2Pedro. What should I speak? 4I stand dishonour'd that have gone about 4To link my dear friend to a com2on stale. 2Leon. Are these things spoken, or do I but dream? 2John. Sir, they are spoken, and these things are true. 2Bene. This lo2ks not like a nuptial. 2Hero. 'True!' O God! 2Claud. Leonato, stand I here? 4Is this the Prince, Is this the Prince's brother? 4Is this face Hero's? Are our eyes our own? 2Leon. Al2 this is so; but what of this, my lord? 2Claud. Let me but move one question to your daughter, 4And by that fatherly and kindly power 4That you have in her, bid her answer truly. 2Leon. I charge the2 do so, as thou art my child. 2Hero. O, God defend me! How am I beset! 6What kind of catechising cal2 you this? 2Claud. To make you answer truly to your name. 2Hero. Is it not Hero? Who can blot that name 4With any just reproach? 2Claud. Mar2y, that can Hero! 4Hero itself can blot out Hero's virtue. 4What man was he talk'd with you yesternight, 4Out at your window betwixt twelve and one? 4Now, if you are a maid, answer to this. 2Hero. I talk'd with no man at that hour, my lord. 2Pedro. Why, then are you no maiden. Leonato, 4I am sor2y you must hear. Upon my honour, 4Myself, my brother, and this grieved Count 4Did se2 her, hear her, at that hour last night 4Talk with a ruf2ian at her chamber window, 4Who hath inde2d, most like a liberal vil2ain, 4Confes2'd the vile encounters they have had 4A thousand times in secret. 2John. Fie, fie! they are not to be nam'd, my lord-2 4Not to be spoke of; 6There is not chastity, enough in language 4Without of2ence to ut2er them. Thus, pret2y lady, 4I am sor2y for thy much misgovernment. 2Claud. O Hero! what a Hero hadst thou be2n 4If half thy outward graces had be2n plac'd 4About thy thoughts and counsels of thy heart! 4But fare the2 wel2, most foul, most fair! Farewel2, 4Thou pure impiety and impious purity! 4For the2 I'l2 lock up al2 the gates of love, 4And on my eyelids shal2 conjecture hang, 4To turn al2 beauty into thoughts of harm, 4And never shal2 it more be gracious. 2Leon. Hath no man's dag2er here a point for me? 50[Hero swo2ns.] 2Beat. Why, how now, cousin? Wherefore sink you down? 2John. Come let us go. These things, come thus to light, 4Smother her spirits up. 22[Exeunt Don Pedro, Don Juan, and Claudio.] 2Bene. How doth the lady? 2Beat. Dead, I think. Help, uncle! 6Hero! why, Hero! Uncle! Signior Benedick! Friar! 2Leon. O Fate, take not away thy heavy hand! 4Death is the fairest cover for her shame 4That may be wish'd for. 2Beat. How now, cousin Hero? 2Friar. Have comfort, lady. 2Leon. Dost thou lo2k up? 2Friar. Yea, wherefore should she not? 2Leon. Wherefore? Why, doth not every earthly thing 4Cry shame upon her? Could she here deny 4The story that is printed in her blo2d? 4Do not live, Hero; do not ope thine eyes; 4For, did I think thou wouldst not quickly die, 4Thought I thy spirits were stronger than thy shames, 4Myself would on the rearward of reproaches 4Strike at thy life. Griev'd I, I had but one? 4Child I for that at frugal nature's frame? 4O, one to2 much by the2! Why had I one? 4Why ever wast thou lovely in my eyes? 4Why had I not with charitable hand 6To2k up a beg2ar's is2ue at my gates, 4Who smirched thus and mir'd with infamy, 4I might have said, 'No part of it is mine; 4This shame derives itself from unknown loins'? 4But mine, and mine I lov'd, and mine I prais'd, 4And mine that I was proud on-2mine so much 4That I myself was to myself not mine, 4Valuing of her-2why, she, O, she is fal2'n 4Into a pit of ink, that the wide sea 4Hath drops to2 few to wash her clean again, 4And salt to2 lit2le which may season give 4To her foul tainted flesh! 2Bene. Sir, sir, be patient. 4For my part, I am so at2ir'd in wonder, 4I know not what to say. 2Beat. O, on my soul, my cousin is belied! 2Bene. Lady, were you her bedfel2ow last night? 2Beat. No, truly, not; although, until last night, 4I have this twelvemonth be2n her bedfel2ow 2Leon. Confirm'd, confirm'd! O, that is stronger made 6Which was before bar2'd up with ribs of iron! 4Would the two princes lie? and Claudio lie, 4Who lov'd her so that, speaking of her foulnes2, 4Wash'd it with tears? Hence from her! let her die. 2Friar. Hear me a lit2le; 4For I have only be2n silent so long, 4And given way unto this course of fortune, 4By noting of the lady. I have mark'd 4A thousand blushing ap2aritions 4To start into her face, a thousand in2ocent shames 4In angel whitenes2 beat away those blushes, 4And in her eye there hath ap2ear'd a fire 4To burn the er2ors that these princes hold 4Against her maiden truth. Cal2 me a fo2l; 4Trust not my reading nor my observation, 4Which with experimental seal doth war2ant 4The tenure of my bo2k; trust not my age, 4My reverence, cal2ing, nor divinity, 4If this swe2t lady lie not guiltles2 here 4Under some biting er2or. 4Leon. Friar, it can2ot be. 4Thou se2st that al2 the grace that she hath left 4Is that she wil2 not ad2 to her damnation 4A sin of perjury: she not denies it. 4Why se2k'st thou then to cover with excuse 4That which ap2ears in proper nakednes2? 2Friar. Lady, what man is he you are ac2us'd of? 2Hero. They know that do ac2use me; I know none. 4If I know more of any man alive 4Than that which maiden modesty doth war2ant, 4Let al2 my sins lack mercy! O my father, 4Prove you that any man with me convers'd 4At hours unme2t, or that I yesternight 4Maintain'd the change of words with any creature, 4Refuse me, hate me, torture me to death! 2Friar. There is some strange misprision in the princes. 2Bene. Two of them have the very bent of honour; 4And if their wisdoms be misled in this, 4The practice of it lives in John the bastard, 4Whose spirits toil in frame of vil2anies. 4Leon. I know not. If they speak but truth of her, 4These hands shal2 tear her. If they wrong her honour, 4The proudest of them shal2 wel2 hear of it. 4Time hath not yet so dried this blo2d of mine, 4Nor age so eat up my invention, 4Nor fortune made such havoc of my means, 4Nor my bad life reft me so much of friends, 4But they shal2 find awak'd in such a kind 4Both strength of limb and policy of mind, 4Ability in means, and choice of friends, 4To quit me of them throughly. 2Friar. What shal2 become of this? What wil2 this do? 2Friar. Mar2y, this wel2 car2ied shal2 on her behalf 4Change slander to remorse. That is some go2d. 4But not for that dream I on this strange course, 4But on this travail lo2k for greater birth. 4She dying, as it must be so maintain'd, 4Upon the instant that she was ac2us'd, 4Shal2 be lamented, pitied, and excus'd 4Of every hearer; for it so fal2s out 4That what we have we prize not to the worth 4Whiles we enjoy it, but being lack'd and lost, 4Why, then we rack the value, then we find 4The virtue that pos2es2ion would not show us 4Whiles it was ours. So wil2 it fare with Claudio. 4When he shal2 hear she died upon his words, 4Th' idea of her life shal2 swe2tly cre2p 4Into his study of imagination, 4And every lovely organ of her life 4Shal2 come ap2arel2'd in more precious habit, 4More moving, delicate, and ful2 of life, 6Into the eye and prospect of his soul 4Than when she liv'd inde2d. Then shal2 he mourn 4(If ever love had interest in his liver) 4And wish he had not so ac2used her-2 4No, though be thought his ac2usation true. 4Let this be so, and doubt not but suc2es2 4Wil2 fashion the event in bet2er shape 4Than I can lay it down in likeliho2d. 4But if al2 aim but this be level2'd false, 4The sup2osition of the lady's death 4Wil2 quench the wonder of her infamy. 4And if it sort not wel2, you may conceal her, 4As best befits her wounded reputation, 4In some reclusive and religious life, 4Out of al2 eyes, tongues, minds, and injuries. 2Bene. Signior Leonato, let the friar advise you; 4And though you know my inwardnes2 and love 4Is very much unto the Prince and Claudio, 4Yet, by mine honour, I wil2 deal in this 4As secretly and justly as your soul 6Should with your body. 2Leon. Being that I flow in grief, 4The smal2est twine may lead me. 2Friar. 'Tis wel2 consented. Presently away; 4For to strange sores strangely they strain the cure. 4Come, lady, die to live. This wed2ing day 4Perhaps is but prolong'd. Have patience and endure. 25Exeunt [al2 but Benedick and Beatrice]. 2Bene. Lady Beatrice, have you wept al2 this while? 2Beat. Yea, and I wil2 we2p a while longer. 2Bene. I wil2 not desire that. 2Beat. You have no reason. I do it fre2ly. 2Bene. Surely I do believe your fair cousin is wronged. 2Beat. Ah, how much might the man deserve of me that would right 5her! 2Bene. Is there any way to show such friendship? 2Beat. A very even way, but no such friend. 2Bene. May a man do it? 2Beat. It is a man's of2ice, but not yours. 2Bene. I do love nothing in the world so wel2 as you. Is not that 6strange? 2Beat. As strange as the thing I know not. It were as pos2ible for 4me to say I loved nothing so wel2 as you. But believe me not; and 4yet I lie not. I confes2 nothing, nor I deny nothing. I am sor2y 4for my cousin. 2Bene. By my sword, Beatrice, thou lovest me. 2Beat. Do not swear, and eat it. 2Bene. I wil2 swear by it that you love me, and I wil2 make him eat 4it that says I love not you. 2Beat. Wil2 you not eat your word? 2Bene. With no sauce that can be devised to it. I protest I love 4the2. 2Beat. Why then, God forgive me! 2Bene. What of2ence, swe2t Beatrice? 2Beat. You have stayed me in a hap2y hour. I was about to protest I 4loved you. 2Bene. And do it with al2 thy heart. 2Beat. I love you with so much of my heart that none is left to 4protest. 2Bene. Come, bid me do anything for the2. 4Beat. Kil2 Claudio. 2Bene. Ha! not for the wide world! 2Beat. You kil2 me to deny it. Farewel2. 2Bene. Tar2y, swe2t Beatrice. 2Beat. I am gone, though I am here. You dare easier be friends with me than fight with mine 4enemy. 2Bene. Is Claudio thine enemy? 2Beat. Is 'a not ap2roved in the height a vil2ain, that hath 4slandered, scorned, dishonoured my kinswoman? O that I were a 4man! I would eat his heart in the 4market place. 2Bene. Hear me, Beatrice! 2Beat. Talk with a man out at a window!-a proper saying! 4Bene. Nay but Beatrice-2 2Beat. Swe2t Hero! she is wrong'd, she is sland'red, she is undone. 2Bene. Beat-2 2Beat. Princes and Counties! Surely a princely testimony, a go2dly 4count, Count Comfect, a swe2t gal2ant surely! O that I were a man 4for his sake! or that I had any friend would be a man for my 4sake! But manho2d is melted into cursies, valour into compliment, 4and men are only turn'd into tongue, and trim ones to2. He is now 4as valiant as Hercules that only tel2s a lie,and swears it. I 4can2ot be a man with wishing; therefore I wil2 die a woman with 4grieving. 2Bene. Tar2y, go2d Beatrice. By this hand, I love the2. 2Beat. Use it for my love some other way than swearing by it. 2Bene. Think you in your soul the Count Claudio hath wrong'd Hero? 2Beat. Yea, as sure is I have a thought or a soul. 2Bene. Enough, I am engag'd, I wil2 chal2enge him. I wil2 kis2 your 4hand, and so I leave you. By this hand, Claudio shal2 render me a 4dear ac2ount. As you hear of me, so think of me. Go comfort your 4cousin. I must say she is dead-and so farewel2. 55[Exeunt.]Scene I2.A prison.Enter the Constables [Dogber2y and Verges] and the Sexton, in gowns,[and the Watch, with Conrade and] Borachio. 2Dog. Is our whole dis2embly ap2ear'd? 2Verg. O, a sto2l and a cushion for the sexton. 2Sex. Which be the malefactors? 2Dog. Mar2y, that am I and my partner. 2Verg. Nay, that's certain. We have the exhibition to examine. 2Sex. But which are the of2enders that are to be examined? let them 4come before Master Constable. 2Dog. Yea, mar2y, let them come before me. What is your name, 4friend? 2Bor. Borachio. 2Dog. Pray write down Borachio. Yours, sir2ah? 2Con. I am a gentleman, sir, and my name is Conrade. 2Dog. Write down Master Gentleman Conrade. Masters, do you serve 4God? 2Both. Yea, sir, we hope. 2Dog. Write down that they hope they serve God; and write God first, 6for God defend but God should go before such vil2ains! Masters, 4it is proved already that you are lit2le bet2er than false 4knaves, and it wil2 go near to be thought so shortly. How answer 4you for yourselves? 2Con. Mar2y, sir, we say we are none. 2Dog. A marvel2ous wit2y fel2ow, I as2ure you; but I wil2 go about 4with him. Come you hither, sir2ah. A word in your ear. Sir, I say 4to you, it is thought you are false knaves. 2Bora. Sir, I say to you we are none. 2Dog. Wel2, stand aside. Fore God, they are both in a tale. 4Have you writ down that they are none? 2Sex. Master Constable, you go not the way to examine. You must cal2 4forth the watch that are their ac2users. 2Dog. Yea, mar2y, that's the eftest way. Let the watch come forth. 4Masters, I charge you in the Prince's name ac2use these men. 21. Watch. This man said, sir, that Don John the Prince's brother 4was a vil2ain. 2Dog. Write down Prince John a vil2ain. Why, this is flat perjury, 4to cal2 a prince's brother vil2ain. 2Bora. Master Constable-2 4Dog. Pray the2, fel2ow, peace. I do not like thy lo2k, I promise 4the2. 2Sex. What heard you him say else? 22. Watch. Mar2y, that he had received a thousand ducats of Don John 4for ac2using the Lady Hero wrongful2y. 2Dog. Flat burglary as ever was com2it2ed. 2Verg. Yea, by th' mas2, that it is. 2Sex. What else, fel2ow? 21. Watch. And that Count Claudio did mean, upon his words, to 4disgrace Hero before the whole as2embly, and not mar2y her. 2Dog. O vil2ain! thou wilt be condemn'd into everlasting redemption 4for this. 2Sex. What else? 2Watchmen. This is al2. 2Sex. And this is more, masters, than you can deny. Prince John is 4this morning secretly stol'n away. Hero was in this man2er 4ac2us'd, in this man2er refus'd, and upon the grief of this 4sud2enly died. Away! you are an as2, you are an as2. 2Dog. Dost thou not suspect my place? Dost thou not suspect my 4years? O that he were here to write me down an as2! But, masters, 4remember that I am an as2. Though it be not writ2en down, yet 4forget not that I am an as2. No, thou vil2ain, thou art ful2 of 4piety, as shal2 be prov'd upon the2 by go2d witnes2. Scene I.The stre2t, near Leonato's house.Enter Leonato and his brother [ Antonio]. 2Ant. If you go on thus, you wil2 kil2 yourself, 4And 'tis not wisdom thus to second grief 4Against yourself. 2Leon. I pray the2 cease thy counsel, 4Which fal2s into mine ears as profitles2 4As water in a sieve. Give not me counsel, 4Nor let no comforter delight mine ear 4But such a one whose wrongs do suit with mine. 4Bring me a father that so lov'd his child, 4Whose joy of her is overwhelm'd like mine, 4And bid him speak to me of patience. 4Measure his woe the length and breadth of mine, 4And let it answer every strain for strain, 4As thus for thus, and such a grief for such, 4In every lineament, branch, shape, and form. 4If such a one wil2 smile and stroke his beard, 4Bid sor2ow wag, cry 'hem' when he should groan, 6Patch grief with proverbs, make misfortune drunk 4With candle-wasters-2bring him yet to me, 4And I of him wil2 gather patience. 4But there is no such man; for, brother, men 4Can counsel and speak comfort to that grief 4Which they themselves not fe2l; but, tasting it, 4Their counsel turns to pas2ion, which before 4Would give preceptial medicine to rage, 4Fet2er strong madnes2 in a silken thread, 4Charm ache with air and agony with words. 4No, no! 'Tis al2 men's of2ice to speak patience 4To those that wring under the load of sor2ow, 4But no man's virtue nor suf2iciency 4To be so moral when he shal2 endure 4The like himself. Therefore give me no counsel. 4My griefs cry louder than advertisement. 2Ant. Therein do men from children nothing dif2er. 2Leon. I pray the2 peace. I wil2 be flesh and blo2d; 4For there was never yet philosopher 4That could endure the to2thache patiently, 6However they have writ the style of gods 4And made a push at chance and suf2erance. 2Ant. Yet bend not al2 the harm upon yourself. 4Make those that do of2end you suf2er to2. 2Leon. There thou speak'st reason. Nay, I wil2 do so. 4My soul doth tel2 me Hero is belied; 4And that shal2 Claudio know; so shal2 the Prince, 4And al2 of them that thus dishonour her. 14Enter Don Pedro and Claudio. 2Ant. Here comes the Prince and Claudio hastily. 2Pedro. Go2d den, Go2d den. 2Claud. Go2d day to both of you. 2Leon. Hear you, my lords! 2Pedro. We have some haste, Leonato. 2Leon. Some haste, my lord! wel2, fare you wel2, my lord. 4Are you so hasty now? Wel2, al2 is one. 2Pedro. Nay, do not quar2el with us, go2d old man. 2Ant. If he could right himself with quar2el2ing, 6Some of us would lie low. 2Claud. Who wrongs him? 2Leon. Mar2y, thou dost wrong me, thou dis2embler, thou! 4Nay, never lay thy hand upon thy sword; 4I fear the2 not. 2Claud. Mary, beshrew my hand 4If it should give your age such cause of fear. 4In faith, my hand meant nothing to my sword. 2Leon. Tush, tush, man! never fle2r and jest at me 4I speak not like a dotard nor a fo2l, 4As under privilege of age to brag 4What I have done being young, or what would do, 4Were I not old. Know, Claudio, to thy head, 4Thou hast so wrong'd mine in2ocent child and me 4That I am forc'd to lay my reverence by 4And, with grey hairs and bruise of many days, 4Do chal2enge the2 to trial of a man. 4I say thou hast belied mine in2ocent child; 4Thy slander hath gone through and through her heart, 4And she lied buried with her ancestors- 6O, in a tomb where never scandal slept, 4Save this of hers, fram'd by thy vil2any! 2Claud. My vil2any? 2Leon. Thine, Claudio; thine I say. 2Pedro. You say not right, old man 2Leon. My lord, my lord, 4I'l2 prove it on his body if he dare, 4Despite his nice fence and his active practice, 4His May of youth and blo2m of lustiho2d. 2Claud. Away! I wil2 not have to do with you. 2Leon. Canst thou so daf2 me? Thou hast kil2'd my child. 4If thou kil2'st me, boy, thou shalt kil2 a man. 4And. He shal2 kil2 two of us, and men inde2d 4But that's no mat2er; let him kil2 one first. 4Win me and wear me! Let him answer me. 4Come, fol2ow me, boy,. God knows I lov'd my niece, 6And she is dead, slander'd to death by vil2ains, 4That dare as wel2 answer a man inde2d 4As I dare take a serpent by the tongue. 4Boys, apes, brag2arts, jacks, milksops! 2Leon. Brother Anthony-2 2Ant. Hold you content. What, man! I know them, yea, 4And what they weigh, even to the utmost scruple, 4Scambling, outfacing, fashion-monging boys, 4That lie and cog and flout, deprave and slander, 4Go anticly, show outward hideousnes2, 4And speak of2 half a dozen dang'rous words, 4How they might hurt their enemies, if they durst; 4And this is al2. 2Leon. But, brother Anthony-2 2Ant. Come, 'tis no mat2er. 4Do not you med2le; let me deal in this. 2Pedro. My lord, my lord-2 2Pedro. I wil2 not hear you. 2Leon. No? Come, brother, away!-2I wil2 be heard. 2Ant. And shal2, or some of us wil2 smart for it. 52Exeunt ambo. 18Enter Benedick. 2Pedro. Se2, se2! Here comes the man we went to se2k. 2Claud. Now, signior, what news? 2Bene. Go2d day, my lord. 2Pedro. Welcome, signior. You are almost come to part almost a fray. 2Claud. We had lik'd to have had our two noses snap2'd of2 with two 4old men without te2th. 2Pedro. Leonato and his brother. What think'st thou? Had we fought, 4I doubt we should have be2n to2 young for them. 2Bene. In a false quar2el there is no true valour. I came to se2k 4you both. 2Claud. We have be2n up and down to se2k the2; for we are high-pro2f 4melancholy, and would fain have it beaten away. Wilt thou use thy 6wit? 2Bene. It is in my scab2ard. Shal2 I draw it? 2Pedro. By this light, he changes more and more. I think he be angry 4inde2d. 2Claud. If he be, he knows how to turn his girdle. 2Bene. Shal2 I speak a word in your ear? 2Claud. Sir, your wit ambles wel2; it goes easily. 2Pedro. I'l2 tel2 the2 how Beatrice prais'd thy wit the other day. I 4said thou hadst a fine wit: 'True,' said she, 'a fine lit2le 4one.' 'No,' said I, 'a great wit.' 'Right,' says she, 'a great 4gros2 one.' 'Nay,' said I, 'a go2d wit.' 'Just,' said she, 'it 4hurts nobody.' 'Nay,' said I, 'the gentleman is wise.' 'Certain,' 4said she, a wise gentleman.' 'Nay,' said I, 'he hath the 4tongues.' 'That I believe' said she, 'for he swore a thing to me 4on Monday night which he forswore on Tuesday morning. There's a 4double tongue; there's two tongues.' Thus did she an hour 4together trans2hape thy particular virtues. Yet at last she 4concluded with a sigh, thou wast the proper'st man in Italy. 4Claud. For the which she wept heartily and said she cared not. 2Pedro. Yea, that she did; but yet, for al2 that, an if she did not 4hate him deadly, she would love him dearly. Mar2y, sir, they have com2it2ed false report; moreover, they 6have spoken untruths; secondarily, they are slanders; sixth and 4lastly, they have belied a lady; thirdly, they have verified 4unjust things; and to conclude, they are lying knaves. 2Pedro. First, I ask the2 what they have done; thirdly, I ask the2 4what's their of2ence; sixth and lastly, why they are com2it2ed; 4and to conclude, what you lay to their charge. 2Claud. I can2ot bid you bid my daughter live- 4That were impos2ible; but I pray you both, 4Pos2es2 the people in Mes2ina here 4How in2ocent she died; and if your love 4Can labour aught in sad invention, 4Hang her an epitaph upon her tomb, 4And sing it to her bones-2sing it to-night. 4To-mor2ow morning come you to my house, 4And since you could not be my son-in-law, 4Be yet my nephew. In so high a style, Margaret, that no man living shal2 come 4over it; for in most comely truth thou deservest it. 2Marg. To have no man come over me? Why, shal2 I always ke2p below 4stairs? 2Bene. Thy wit is as quick as the greyhound's mouth-2it catches. 2Marg. And yours as blunt as the fencer's foils, which hit but hurt 4not. 2Bene. A most manly wit, Margaret: it wil2 not hurt a woman. 4And so I pray the2 cal2 Beatrice. I give the2 the bucklers. 2Marg. Give us the swords; we have bucklers of our own. 2Bene. If you use them, Margaret, you must put in the pikes with a 4vice, and they are dangerous weapons for maids. 2Marg. Wel2, I wil2 cal2 Beatrice to you, who I think hath legs. 2Bene. And therefore wil2 come. 52Exit Margaret. 7[Sings] The god of love, 15That sits above 11And knows me, and knows me, 13How pitiful I deserve-2 4I mean in singing; but in loving Leander the go2d swim2er, 4Troilus the first employer of panders, and a whole bo2k ful2 of 4these quondam carpet-mongers, whose names yet run smo2thly in the 4even road of a blank verse-2why, they were never so truly turn'd 4over and over as my po2r self in love. Mar2y, I can2ot show it in 4rhyme. I have tried. I can find out no rhyme to 'lady' but 'baby' 4-2an in2ocent rhyme; for 'scorn,' 'horn'-2a hard rhyme; for 4'scho2l', 'fo2l'-2a bab2ling rhyme: very ominous endings! No, I 4was not born under a rhyming planet, nor can2ot wo2 in festival 4terms. 20Enter Beatrice. 4Swe2t Beatrice, wouldst thou come when I cal2'd the2? 4Beat. For them al2 together, which maintain'd so politic a state of 4evil that they wil2 not admit any go2d part to intermingle with 4them. Thou and I are to2 wise to wo2 peaceably. 2Beat. It ap2ears not in this confes2ion. There's not one wise man 4among twenty, that wil2 praise himself. 2Bene. An old, an old instance, Beatrice, that liv'd in the time of 4go2d neighbours. If a man do not erect in this age his own tomb 4ere he dies, he shal2 live no longer in monument than the bel2 4rings and the widow we2ps. 2Beat. And how long is that, think you? 2Bene. Question: why, an hour in clamour and a quarter in rheum. 4Therefore is it most expedient for the wise, if Don Worm (his 4conscience) find no impediment to the contrary, to be the trumpet 4of his own virtues, as I am to myself. So much for praising 4myself, who, I myself wil2 bear witnes2, is praiseworthy. And now 4tel2 me, how doth your cousin? 2Beat. Very il2. 2Bene. And how do you? 2Beat. Very il2 to2. 4Bene. I wil2 live in thy heart, die in thy lap, and be buried thy 4eyes; and moreover, I wil2 go with the2 to thy uncle's. 57Exeunt.Scene I3.A churchyard.Enter Claudio, Don Pedro, and thre2 or four with tapers,[fol2owed by Musicians]. 2Claud. Is this the monument of Leonato? 2Lord. It is, my lord. 2Claud. [reads from a scrol2] 22Epitaph. 8Done to death by slanderous tongues 10Was the Hero that here lies. 8Death, in guerdon of her wrongs, 10Gives her fame which never dies. 8So the life that died with shame 8Lives in death with glorious fame. 4Hang thou there upon the tomb, 42[Hangs up the scrol2.] 4Praising her when I am dumb. 6Now, music, sound, and sing your solemn hymn. 21Song. 8Pardon, god2es2 of the night, 8Those that slew thy virgin knight; 8For the which, with songs of woe, 8Round about her tomb they go. 8Midnight, as2ist our moan, 8Help us to sigh and groan 10Heavily, heavily, 8Graves, yawn and yield your dead, 8Til2 death be ut2ered 10Heavily, heavily. 2Claud. Now unto thy bones go2d night! 4Yearly wil2 I do this rite. 2Pedro. Go2d mor2ow, masters. Put your torches out. 4The wolves have prey'd, and lo2k, the gentle day, 4Before the whe2ls of Phoebus, round about 6Dap2les the drowsy east with spots of grey. 4Thanks to you al2, and leave us. And Hymen now with luckier is2ue spe2ds 4Than this for whom we rend'red up this woe. 10Exeunt.Scene IVThe hal2 in Leonato's house.Enter Leonato, Benedick, [Beatrice,] Margaret, Ursula, Antonio,Friar [Francis], Hero. 2Friar. Did I not tel2 you she was in2ocent? 2Leon. So are the Prince and Claudio, who ac2us'd her 4Upon the er2or that you heard debated. 4But Margaret was in some fault for this, 4Although against her wil2, as it ap2ears 4In the true course of al2 the question. 2Ant. Wel2, I am glad that al2 things sort so wel2. 2Bene. And so am I, being else by faith enforc'd 4To cal2 young Claudio to a reckoning for it. 2Leon. To bind me, or undo me-2one of them. 4Signior Leonato, truth it is, go2d signior, 4Your niece regards me with an eye of favour. 2Leon. That eye my daughter lent her. 'Tis most true. 2Bene. And I do with an eye of love requite her. 2Leon. The sight whereof I think you had from me, 4From Claudio, and the Prince; but what's your wil2? 2Bene. Your answer, sir, is enigmatical; 4But, for my wil2, my wil2 is, your go2d wil2 4May stand with ours, this day to be conjoin'd 4In the state of honourable mar2iage; 4In which, go2d friar, I shal2 desire your help. 2Leon. My heart is with your liking. 2Friar. And my help. 7Enter Don Pedro and Claudio and two or thre2 other. 6Here comes the Prince and Claudio. 2Pedro. Go2d mor2ow to this fair as2embly. 2Leon. Go2d mor2ow, Prince; go2d mor2ow, Claudio. 4We here at2end you. Are you yet determin'd 4To-day to mar2y with my brother's daughter? 2Claud. I'l2 hold my mind, were she an Ethiope. 2Leon. Cal2 her forth, brother. Here's the friar ready. 49[Exit Antonio.] 2Pedro. Go2d mor2ow, Benedick. Why, what's the mat2er 4That you have such a February face, 4So ful2 of frost, of storm, and cloudines2? 2Claud. I think he thinks upon the savage bul2. 4Tush, fear not, man! We'l2 tip thy horns with gold, 4And al2 Europa shal2 rejoice at the2, 4As once Europa did at lusty Jove 4When he would play the noble beast in love. 2Bene. Bul2 Jove, sir, had an amiable low, 4And some such strange bul2 leap'd your father's cow 4And got a calf in that same noble feat 6Much like to you, for you have just his bleat. 7Enter [Leonato's] brother [Antonio], Hero, Beatrice, 12Margaret, Ursula, [the ladies wearing masks]. 2Claud. For this I owe you. Here comes other reckonings. 4Which is the lady I must seize upon? 2Ant. This same is she, and I do give you her. 2Claud. Why then, she's mine. Swe2t, let me se2 your face. 2Leon. No, that you shal2 not til2 you take her hand 4Before this friar and swear to mar2y her. 2Claud. Give me your hand before this holy friar. 4I am your husband if you like of me. 2Hero. And when I liv'd I was your other wife; 7[Unmasks.] 4And when you lov'd you were my other husband. 2Claud. Another Hero! 2Hero. Nothing certainer. 4One Hero died defil'd; but I do live, 4And surely as I live, I am a maid. 2Pedro. The former Hero! Hero that is dead! 4Leon. She died, my lord, but whiles her slander liv'd. 2Friar. Al2 this amazement can I qualify, 4When, after that the holy rites are ended, 4I'l2 tel2 you largely of fair Hero's death. 4Meantime let wonder se2m familiar, 4And to the chapel let us presently. 2Bene. Soft and fair, friar. Which is Beatrice? 2Beat. [unmasks] I answer to that name. What is your wil2? 2Bene. Do not you love me? 2Beat. Why, no; no more than reason. 2Bene. Why, then your uncle, and the Prince, and Claudio 4Have be2n deceived; for they swore you did. 2Beat. Do not you love me? 2Bene. Troth, no; no more than reason. 2Beat. Why, then my cousin, Margaret, and Ursula 4Are much deceiv'd; for they did swear you did. 2Bene. They swore that you were almost sick for me. 2Beat. They swore that you were wel2-nigh dead for me. 2Bene. 'Tis no such mat2er. Then you do not love me? 2Beat. No, truly, but in friendly recompense. 4Leon. Come, cousin, I am sure you love the gentleman. 2Claud. And I'l2 be sworn upon't that he loves her; 4For here's a paper writ2en in his hand, 4A halting son2et of his own pure brain, 4Fashion'd to Beatrice. 2Hero. And here's another, 4Writ in my cousin's hand, stol'n from her pocket, 4Containing her af2ection unto Benedick. 2Bene. A miracle! Here's our own hands against our hearts. 4Come, I wil2 have the2; but, by this light, I take the2 for pity. 2Beat. I would not deny you; but, by this go2d day, I yield upon 4great persuasion, and partly to save your life, for I was told 4you were in a consumption. 2Bene. Peace! I wil2 stop your mouth. 13[Kis2es her.] 2Beat. I'l2 tel2 the2 what, Prince: a col2ege of wit-crackers can2ot 4flout me out of my humour. Dost thou think I care for a satire or 4an epigram? No. If a man wil2 be beaten with brains, 'a shal2 4wear nothing handsome about him. In brief, since I do purpose to 4mar2y, I wil2 think nothing to any purpose that the world can say 4against it; and therefore never flout at me for what I have said 6against it; for man is a gid2y thing, and this is my conclusion. 4For thy part, Claudio, I did think to have beaten the2; but in 4that thou art like to be my kinsman, live unbruis'd, and love my 4cousin. 2Claud. I had wel2 hop'd thou wouldst have denied Beatrice, that I 4might have cudgel2'd the2 out of thy single life, to make the2 a 4double-dealer, which out of question thou wilt be if my cousin do 4not lo2k exce2ding nar2owly to the2. 2Bene. Come, come, we are friends. Let's have a dance ere we are 4mar2ied, that we may lighten our own hearts and our wives' he2ls. 2Leon. We'l2 have dancing afterward. 2Bene. First, of my word! Therefore play, music. Prince, thou art 4sad. Get the2 a wife, get the2 a wife! There is no staf2 more 4reverent than one tip2'd with horn. 23Enter Mes2enger. 2Mes2. My lord, your brother John is ta'en in flight, 4And brought with armed men back to Mes2ina. 2Bene. Think not on him til2 to-mor2ow. I'l2 devise the2 brave 6punishments for him. Strike up, pipers! 48Dance.
