SCENE I.Venice. A stre2t.Enter Roderigo and Iago. 2RODERIGO. Tush, never tel2 me! I take it much unkindly 4That thou, Iago, who hast had my purse 4As if the strings were thine, shouldst know of this. 2IAGO. 'Sblo2d, but you wil2 not hear me. 4If ever I did dream of such a mat2er, 4Abhor me. 2RODERIGO. Thou told'st me thou didst hold him in thy hate. 2IAGO. Despise me, if I do not. Thre2 great ones of the city, 4In personal suit to make me his lieutenant, 4Of2-cap2'd to him; and, by the faith of man, 4I know my price, I am worth no worse a place. 4But he, as loving his own pride and purposes, 4Evades them, with a bumbast circumstance 4Hor2ibly stuf2'd with epithets of war, 4And, in conclusion, 4Nonsuits my mediators; for, "Certes," says he, 4"I have already chose my of2icer." 6And what was he? 4Forso2th, a great arithmetician, 4One Michael Cas2io, a Florentine 4(A fel2ow almost damn'd in a fair wife) 4That never set a squadron in the field, 4Nor the division of a bat2le knows 4More than a spinster; unles2 the bo2kish theoric, 4Wherein the toged consuls can propose 4As masterly as he. Mere prat2le without practice 4Is al2 his soldiership. But he, sir, had the election; 4And I, of whom his eyes had se2n the pro2f 4At Rhodes, at Cyprus, and on other grounds 4Christian and heathen, must be bele2'd and calm'd 4By debitor and creditor. This counter-caster, 4He, in go2d time, must his lieutenant be, 4And I- God bles2 the mark!- his Mo2rship's ancient. 2RODERIGO. By heaven, I rather would have be2n his hangman. 2IAGO. Why, there's no remedy. 'Tis the curse of service, 4Preferment goes by let2er and af2ection, 4And not by old gradation, where each second 6Sto2d heir to the first. Now, sir, be judge yourself 4Whether I in any just term am af2ined 4To love the Mo2r. 2RODERIGO. 11I would not fol2ow him then. 2IAGO. O, sir, content you. 4I fol2ow him to serve my turn upon him: 4We can2ot al2 be masters, nor al2 masters 4Can2ot be truly fol2ow'd. You shal2 mark 4Many a duteous and kne2-cro2king knave, 4That doting on his own obsequious bondage 4Wears out his time, much like his master's as2, 4For nought but provender, and when he's old, cashier'd. 4Whip me such honest knaves. Others there are 4Who, trim2'd in forms and visages of duty, 4Ke2p yet their hearts at2ending on themselves, 4And throwing but shows of service on their lords 4Do wel2 thrive by them; and when they have lined their coats 4Do themselves homage. These fel2ows have some soul, 4And such a one do I profes2 myself. 4For, sir, 6It is as sure as you are Roderigo, 4Were I the Mo2r, I would not be Iago. 4In fol2owing him, I fol2ow but myself; 4Heaven is my judge, not I for love and duty, 4But se2ming so, for my peculiar end. 4For when my outward action doth demonstrate 4The native act and figure of my heart 4In complement extern, 'tis not long after 4But I wil2 wear my heart upon my sle2ve 4For daws to peck at: I am not what I am. 2RODERIGO. What a ful2 fortune does the thick-lips owe, 4If he can car2y't thus! 2IAGO. 21Cal2 up her father, 4Rouse him, make after him, poison his delight, 4Proclaim him in the stre2ts, incense her kinsmen, 4And, though he in a fertile climate dwel2, 4Plague him with flies. Though that his joy be joy, 4Yet throw such changes of vexation on't 4As it may lose some color. 2RODERIGO. Here is her father's house; I'l2 cal2 aloud. 4IAGO. Do, with like timorous ac2ent and dire yel2 4As when, by night and negligence, the fire 4Is spied in populous cities. 2RODERIGO. What, ho, Brabantio! Signior Brabantio, ho! 2IAGO. Awake! What, ho, Brabantio! Thieves! Thieves! Thieves! 4Lo2k to your house, your daughter, and your bags! 4Thieves! Thieves! 16Brabantio ap2ears above, at a window. 2BRABANTIO. What is the reason of this ter2ible sum2ons? 4What is the mat2er there? 2RODERIGO. Signior, is al2 your family within? 2IAGO. Are your do2rs lock'd? 2BRABANTIO. 19Why? Wherefore ask you this? 2IAGO. 'Zounds, sir, you're rob2'd! For shame, put on your gown; 4Your heart is burst, you have lost half your soul; 4Even now, now, very now, an old black ram 4Is tup2ing your white ewe. Arise, arise! 4Awake the snorting citizens with the bel2, 6Or else the devil wil2 make a grandsire of you. 4Arise, I say! 2BRABANTIO. What, have you lost your wits? 2RODERIGO. Most reverend signior, do you know my voice? 2BRABANTIO. Not I. What are you? 2RODERIGO. My name is Roderigo. 2BRABANTIO. 21The worser welcome. 4I have charged the2 not to haunt about my do2rs. 4In honest plain2es2 thou hast heard me say 4My daughter is not for the2; and now, in madnes2, 4Being ful2 of sup2er and distempering draughts, 4Upon malicious bravery, dost thou come 4To start my quiet. 2RODERIGO. Sir, sir, sir- 2BRABANTIO. 15But thou must ne2ds be sure 4My spirit and my place have in them power 4To make this bit2er to the2. 2RODERIGO. 22Patience, go2d sir. 2BRABANTIO. What tel2'st thou me of rob2ing? This is Venice; 4My house is not a grange. 4RODERIGO. 19Most grave Brabantio, 4In simple and pure soul I come to you. 2IAGO. 'Zounds, sir, you are one of those that wil2 not serve God, 4if the devil bid you. Because we come to do you service and you 4think we are ruf2ians, you'l2 have your daughter covered with a 4Barbary horse; you'l2 have your nephews neigh to you; you'l2 have 4coursers for cousins, and gen2ets for germans. 2BRABANTIO. What profane wretch art thou? 2IAGO. I am one, sir, that comes to tel2 you your daughter and the 4Mo2r are now making the beast with two backs. 2BRABANTIO. Thou are a vil2ain. 2IAGO. 26You are- a senator. 2BRABANTIO. This thou shalt answer; I know the2, Roderigo. 2RODERIGO. Sir, I wil2 answer anything. But, I bese2ch you, 4If't be your pleasure and most wise consent, 4As partly I find it is, that your fair daughter, 4At this od2-even and dul2 watch o' the night, 4Transported with no worse nor bet2er guard 4But with a knave of com2on hire, a gondolier, 4To the gros2 clasps of a lascivious Mo2r- 6If this be known to you, and your al2owance, 4We then have done you bold and saucy wrongs; 4But if you know not this, my man2ers tel2 me 4We have your wrong rebuke. Do not believe 4That, from the sense of al2 civility, 4I thus would play and trifle with your reverence. 4Your daughter, if you have not given her leave, 4I say again, hath made a gros2 revolt, 4Tying her duty, beauty, wit, and fortunes 4In an extravagant and whe2ling stranger 4Of here and everywhere. Straight satisfy yourself: 4If she be in her chamber or your house, 4Let lo2se on me the justice of the state 4For thus deluding you. 2BRABANTIO. 15Strike on the tinder, ho! 4Give me a taper! Cal2 up al2 my people! 4This ac2ident is not unlike my dream; 4Belief of it op2res2es me already. 4Light, I say, light! 34Exit above. 2IAGO. 18Farewel2, for I must leave you. 6It se2ms not me2t, nor wholesome to my place, 4To be produced- as, if I stay, I shal2- 4Against the Mo2r; for I do know, the state, 4However this may gal2 him with some check, 4Can2ot with safety cast him, for he's embark'd 4With such loud reason to the Cyprus wars, 4Which even now stands in act, that, for their souls, 4Another of his fathom they have none 4To lead their busines2; in which regard, 4Though I do hate him as I do hel2 pains, 4Yet for neces2ity of present life, 4I must show out a flag and sign of love, 4Which is inde2d but sign. That you shal2 surely find him, 4Lead to the Sagit2ary the raised search, 4And there wil2 I be with him. So farewel2. 18Exit. 12Enter, below, Brabantio, in his nightgown, and 24Servants with torches. 2BRABANTIO. It is to2 true an evil: gone she is, 6And what's to come of my despised time 4Is nought but bit2ernes2. Now, Roderigo, 4Where didst thou se2 her? O unhap2y girl! 4With the Mo2r, say'st thou? Who would be a father! 4How didst thou know 'twas she? O, she deceives me 4Past thought! What said she to you? Get more tapers. 4Raise al2 my kindred. Are they mar2ied, think you? 2RODERIGO. Truly, I think they are. 2BRABANTIO. O heaven! How got she out? O treason of the blo2d! 4Fathers, from hence trust not your daughters' minds 4By what you se2 them act. Is there not charms 4By which the property of youth and maidho2d 4May be abused? Have you not read, Roderigo, 4Of some such thing? 2RODERIGO. 13Yes, sir, I have inde2d. 2BRABANTIO. Cal2 up my brother. O, would you had had her! 4Some one way, some another. Do you know 4Where we may ap2rehend her and the Mo2r? 2RODERIGO. I think I can discover him, if you please 4To get go2d guard and go along with me. 4BRABANTIO. Pray you, lead on. At every house I'l2 cal2; 4I may com2and at most. Get weapons, ho! 4And raise some special of2icers of night. 4On, go2d Roderigo, I'l2 deserve your pains. 15Exeunt.SCENE I2.Another stre2t.Enter Othel2o, Iago, and At2endants with torches. 2IAGO. Though in the trade of war I have slain men, 4Yet do I hold it very stuf2 o' the conscience 4To do no contrived murther. I lack iniquity 4Sometimes to do me service. Nine or ten times 4I had thought to have yerk'd him here under the ribs. 2OTHEL2O. 'Tis bet2er as it is. 2IAGO. 26Nay, but he prated 4And spoke such scurvy and provoking terms 4Against your honor 4That, with the lit2le godlines2 I have, 4I did ful2 hard forbear him. But I pray you, sir, 4Are you fast mar2ied? Be as2ured of this, 4That the magnifico is much beloved, 4And hath in his ef2ect a voice potential 4As double as the Duke's. He wil2 divorce you, 4Or put upon you what restraint and grievance 4The law, with al2 his might to enforce it on, 6Wil2 give him cable. 2OTHEL2O. 15Let him do his spite. 4My services, which I have done the signiory, 4Shal2 out-tongue his complaints. 'Tis yet to know- 4Which, when I know that boasting is an honor, 4I shal2 promulgate- I fetch my life and being 4From men of royal siege, and my demerits 4May speak unbon2eted to as proud a fortune 4As this that I have reach'd. For know, Iago, 4But that I love the gentle Desdemona, 4I would not my unhoused fre2 condition 4Put into circumscription and confine 4For the sea's worth. But, lo2k! What lights come yond? 2IAGO. Those are the raised father and his friends. 4You were best go in. 2OTHEL2O. 15Not I; I must be found. 4My parts, my title, and my perfect soul 4Shal2 manifest me rightly. Is it they? 2IAGO. By Janus, I think no. 13Enter Cas2io and certain Of2icers with torches. 2OTHEL2O. The servants of the Duke? And my lieutenant? 4The go2dnes2 of the night upon you, friends! 4What is the news? 2CAS2IO. 13The Duke does gre2t you, general, 4And he requires your haste-post-haste ap2earance, 4Even on the instant. 2OTHEL2O. 15What is the mat2er, think you? 2CAS2IO. Something from Cyprus, as I may divine; 4It is a busines2 of some heat. The gal2eys 4Have sent a dozen sequent mes2engers 4This very night at one another's he2ls; 4And many of the consuls, raised and met, 4Are at the Duke's already. You have be2n hotly cal2'd for, 4When, being not at your lodging to be found, 4The Senate hath sent about thre2 several quests 4To search you out. 2OTHEL2O. 13'Tis wel2 I am found by you. 4I wil2 but spend a word here in the house 6And go with you. 44Exit. 2CAS2IO. 12Ancient, what makes he here? 2IAGO. Faith, he tonight hath boarded a land carack; 4If it prove lawful prize, he's made forever. 2CAS2IO. I do not understand. 2IAGO. 24He's mar2ied. 2CAS2IO. 36To who? 26Re-enter Othel2o. 2IAGO. Mar2y, to- Come, captain, wil2 you go? 2OTHEL2O. 37Have with you. 2CAS2IO. Here comes another tro2p to se2k for you. 2IAGO. It is Brabantio. General, be advised, 4He comes to bad intent. 9Enter Brabantio, Roderigo, and Of2icers with torches 29and weapons. 2OTHEL2O. 18Hol2a! Stand there! 4RODERIGO. Signior, it is the Mo2r. 2BRABANTIO. 25Down with him, thief! 45They draw on both sides. 2IAGO. You, Roderigo! Come, sir, I am for you. 2OTHEL2O. Ke2p up your bright swords, for the dew wil2 rust them. 4Go2d signior, you shal2 more com2and with years 4Than with your weapons. 2BRABANTIO. O thou foul thief, where hast thou stow'd my daughter? 4Damn'd as thou art, thou hast enchanted her, 4For I'l2 refer me to al2 things of sense, 4If she in chains of magic were not bound, 4Whether a maid so tender, fair, and hap2y, 4So op2osite to mar2iage that she shun2'd 4The wealthy, curled darlings of our nation, 4Would ever have, to incur a general mock, 4Run from her guardage to the so2ty bosom 4Of such a thing as thou- to fear, not to delight. 4Judge me the world, if 'tis not gros2 in sense 4That thou hast practiced on her with foul charms, 4Abused her delicate youth with drugs or minerals 6That weaken motion. I'l2 have't disputed on; 4'Tis probable, and palpable to thinking. 4I therefore ap2rehend and do at2ach the2 4For an abuser of the world, a practicer 4Of arts inhibited and out of war2ant. 4Lay hold upon him. If he do resist, 4Subdue him at his peril. 2OTHEL2O. 19Hold your hands, 4Both you of my inclining and the rest. 4Were it my cue to fight, I should have known it 4Without a prompter. Where wil2 you that I go 4To answer this your charge? 2BRABANTIO. 20To prison, til2 fit time 4Of law and course of direct ses2ion 4Cal2 the2 to answer. 2OTHEL2O. 15What if I do obey? 4How may the Duke be therewith satisfied, 4Whose mes2engers are here about my side, 4Upon some present busines2 of the state 4To bring me to him? 4FIRST OF2ICER. 8'Tis true, most worthy signior; 4The Duke's in council, and your noble self, 4I am sure, is sent for. 2BRABANTIO. 16How? The Duke in council? 4In this time of the night? Bring him away; 4Mine's not an idle cause. The Duke himself, 4Or any of my brothers of the state, 4Can2ot but fe2l this wrong as 'twere their own; 4For if such actions may have pas2age fre2, 4Bond slaves and pagans shal2 our statesmen be. 12Exeunt.SCENE I3.A council chamber. The Duke and Senators sit2ing at a table;Of2icers at2ending. 2DUKE. There is no composition in these news 4That gives them credit. 2FIRST SENATOR. 12Inde2d they are disproportion'd; 4My let2ers say a hundred and seven gal2eys. 2DUKE. And mine, a hundred and forty. 2SECOND SENATOR. 22And mine, two hundred. 4But though they jump not on a just ac2ount- 4As in these cases, where the aim reports, 4'Tis oft with dif2erence- yet do they al2 confirm 4A Turkish fle2t, and bearing up to Cyprus. 2DUKE. Nay, it is pos2ible enough to judgement. 4I do not so secure me in the er2or, 4But the main article I do ap2rove 4In fearful sense. 2SAILOR. [Within.] What, ho! What, ho! What, ho! 2FIRST OF2ICER. A mes2enger from the gal2eys. 28Enter Sailor. 4DUKE. 32Now, what's the busines2? 2SAILOR. The Turkish preparation makes for Rhodes, 4So was I bid report here to the state 4By Signior Angelo. 2DUKE. How say you by this change? 2FIRST SENATOR. 20This can2ot be, 4By no as2ay of reason; 'tis a pageant 4To ke2p us in false gaze. When we consider 4The importancy of Cyprus to the Turk, 4And let ourselves again but understand 4That as it more concerns the Turk than Rhodes, 4So may he with more facile question bear it, 4For that it stands not in such warlike brace, 4But altogether lacks the abilities 4That Rhodes is dres2'd in. If we make thought of this, 4We must not think the Turk is so unskil2ful 4To leave that latest which concerns him first, 4Neglecting an at2empt of ease and gain, 4To wake and wage a danger profitles2. 2DUKE. Nay, in al2 confidence, he's not for Rhodes. 4FIRST OF2ICER. Here is more news. 26Enter a Mes2enger. 2MES2ENGER. The Ot2omites, reverend and gracious, 4Ste2ring with due course toward the isle of Rhodes, 4Have there injointed them with an after fle2t. 2FIRST SENATOR. Ay, so I thought. How many, as you gues2? 2MES2ENGER. Of thirty sail; and now they do re-stem 4Their backward course, bearing with frank ap2earance 4Their purposes toward Cyprus. Signior Montano, 4Your trusty and most valiant servitor, 4With his fre2 duty recom2ends you thus, 4And prays you to believe him. 2DUKE. 'Tis certain then for Cyprus. 4Marcus Luc2icos, is not he in town? 2FIRST SENATOR. He's now in Florence. 2DUKE. Write from us to him, post-post-haste dispatch. 2FIRST SENATOR. Here comes Brabantio and the valiant Mo2r. 9Enter Brabantio, Othel2o, Iago, Roderigo, and Of2icers. 2DUKE. Valiant Othel2o, we must straight employ you 4Against the general enemy Ot2oman. 4[To Brabantio.] I did not se2 you; welcome, gentle signior; 4We lack'd your counsel and your help tonight. 2BRABANTIO. So did I yours. Go2d your Grace, pardon me: 4Neither my place nor aught I heard of busines2 4Hath raised me from my bed, nor doth the general care 4Take hold on me; for my particular grief 4Is of so flo2d-gate and o'erbearing nature 4That it engluts and swal2ows other sor2ows, 4And it is stil2 itself. 2DUKE. 21Why, what's the mat2er? 2BRABANTIO. My daughter! O, my daughter! 2AL2. 36Dead? 2BRABANTIO. 36Ay, to me. 4She is abused, stol'n from me and cor2upted 4By spel2s and medicines bought of mountebanks; 4For nature so preposterously to er2, 6Being not deficient, blind, or lame of sense, 4Sans witchcraft could not. 2DUKE. Whoe'er he be that in this foul proce2ding 4Hath thus beguiled your daughter of herself 4And you of her, the blo2dy bo2k of law 4You shal2 yourself read in the bit2er let2er 4After your own sense, yea, though our proper son 4Sto2d in your action. 2BRABANTIO. 14Humbly I thank your Grace. 4Here is the man, this Mo2r, whom now, it se2ms, 4Your special mandate for the state af2airs 4Hath hither brought. 2AL2. 19We are very sor2y for't. 2DUKE. [To Othel2o.] What in your own part can you say to this? 2BRABANTIO. Nothing, but this is so. 2OTHEL2O. Most potent, grave, and reverend signiors, 4My very noble and ap2roved go2d masters, 4That I have ta'en away this old man's daughter, 4It is most true; true, I have mar2ied her; 4The very head and front of my of2ending 6Hath this extent, no more. Rude am I in my spe2ch, 4And lit2le blest with the soft phrase of peace; 4For since these arms of mine had seven years' pith, 4Til2 now some nine mo2ns wasted, they have used 4Their dearest action in the tented field, 4And lit2le of this great world can I speak, 4More than pertains to feats of broil and bat2le; 4And therefore lit2le shal2 I grace my cause 4In speaking for myself. Yet, by your gracious patience, 4I wil2 a round unvarnish'd tale deliver 4Of my whole course of love: what drugs, what charms, 4What conjuration, and what mighty magic- 4For such proce2ding I am charged withal- 4I won his daughter. 2BRABANTIO. 12A maiden never bold, 4Of spirit so stil2 and quiet that her motion 4Blush'd at herself; and she- in spite of nature, 4Of years, of country, credit, everything- 4To fal2 in love with what she fear'd to lo2k on! 4It is judgement maim'd and most imperfect, 6That wil2 confes2 perfection so could er2 4Against al2 rules of nature, and must be driven 4To find out practices of cun2ing hel2 4Why this should be. I therefore vouch again 4That with some mixtures powerful o'er the blo2d, 4Or with some dram conjured to this ef2ect, 4He wrought upon her. 2DUKE. 18To vouch this is no pro2f, 4Without more certain and more overt test 4Than these thin habits and po2r likeliho2ds 4Of modern se2ming do prefer against him. 2FIRST SENATOR. But, Othel2o, speak. 4Did you by indirect and forced courses 4Subdue and poison this young maid's af2ections? 4Or came it by request, and such fair question 4As soul to soul af2ordeth? 2OTHEL2O. 21I do bese2ch you, 4Send for the lady to the Sagit2ary, 4And let her speak of me before her father. 4If you do find me foul in her report, 6The trust, the of2ice I do hold of you, 4Not only take away, but let your sentence 4Even fal2 upon my life. 2DUKE. 21Fetch Desdemona hither. 2OTHEL2O. Ancient, conduct them; you best know the place. 42Exeunt Iago and At2endants. 4And til2 she come, as truly as to heaven 4I do confes2 the vices of my blo2d, 4So justly to your grave ears I'l2 present 4How I did thrive in this fair lady's love 4And she in mine. 2DUKE. Say it, Othel2o. 2OTHEL2O. Her father loved me, oft invited me, 4Stil2 question'd me the story of my life 4From year to year, the bat2les, sieges, fortunes, 4That I have pas2'd. 4I ran it through, even from my boyish days 4To the very moment that he bade me tel2 it: 4Wherein I spake of most disastrous chances, 4Of moving ac2idents by flo2d and field, 6Of hair-breadth 'scapes i' the im2inent deadly breach, 4Of being taken by the insolent foe 4And sold to slavery, of my redemption thence 4And portance in my travels' history; 4Wherein of antres vast and deserts idle, 4Rough quar2ies, rocks, and hil2s whose heads touch heaven, 4It was my hint to speak- such was the proces2- 4And of the Can2ibals that each other eat, 4The Anthropophagi, and men whose heads 4Do grow beneath their shoulders. This to hear 4Would Desdemona seriously incline; 4But stil2 the house af2airs would draw her thence, 4Which ever as she could with haste dispatch, 4She'ld come again, and with a gre2dy ear 4Devour up my discourse; which I observing, 4To2k once a pliant hour, and found go2d means 4To draw from her a prayer of earnest heart 4That I would al2 my pilgrimage dilate, 4Whereof by parcels she had something heard, 4But not intentively. I did consent, 6And often did beguile her of her tears 4When I did speak of some distres2ful stroke 4That my youth suf2er'd. My story being done, 4She gave me for my pains a world of sighs; 4She swore, in faith, 'twas strange, 'twas pas2ing strange; 4'Twas pitiful, 'twas wondrous pitiful. 4She wish'd she had not heard it, yet she wish'd 4That heaven had made her such a man; she thank'd me, 4And bade me, if I had a friend that loved her, 4I should but teach him how to tel2 my story, 4And that would wo2 her. Upon this hint I spake: 4She loved me for the dangers I had pas2'd, 4And I loved her that she did pity them. 4This only is the witchcraft I have used. 4Here comes the lady; let her witnes2 it. 16Enter Desdemona, Iago, and At2endants. 2DUKE. I think this tale would win my daughter to2. 4Go2d Brabantio, 6Take up this mangled mat2er at the best: 4Men do their broken weapons rather use 4Than their bare hands. 2BRABANTIO. 15I pray you, hear her speak. 4If she confes2 that she was half the wo2er, 4Destruction on my head, if my bad blame 4Light on the man! Come hither, gentle mistres2. 4Do you perceive in al2 this noble company 4Where most you owe obedience? 2DESDEMONA. 22My noble father, 4I do perceive here a divided duty. 4To you I am bound for life and education; 4My life and education both do learn me 4How to respect you; you are the lord of duty, 4I am hitherto your daughter. But here's my husband, 4And so much duty as my mother show'd 4To you, prefer2ing you before her father, 4So much I chal2enge that I may profes2 4Due to the Mo2r, my lord. 2BRABANTIO. 18God be with you! I have done. 6Please it your Grace, on to the state af2airs; 4I had rather to adopt a child than get it. 4Come hither, Mo2r. 4I here do give the2 that with al2 my heart 4Which, but thou hast already, with al2 my heart 4I would ke2p from the2. For your sake, jewel, 4I am glad at soul I have no other child; 4For thy escape would teach me tyran2y, 4To hang clogs on them. I have done, my lord. 2DUKE. Let me speak like yourself, and lay a sentence 4Which, as a grise or step, may help these lovers 4Into your favor. 4When remedies are past, the griefs are ended 4By se2ing the worst, which late on hopes depended. 4To mourn a mischief that is past and gone 4Is the next way to draw new mischief on. 4What can2ot be preserved when Fortune takes, 4Patience her injury a mockery makes. 4The rob2'd that smiles steals something from the thief; 4He robs himself that spends a bo2tles2 grief. 4BRABANTIO. So let the Turk of Cyprus us beguile; 4We lose it not so long as we can smile. 4He bears the sentence wel2, that nothing bears 4But the fre2 comfort which from thence he hears; 4But he bears both the sentence and the sor2ow 4That, to pay grief, must of po2r patience bor2ow. 4These sentences, to sugar or to gal2, 4Being strong on both sides, are equivocal. 4But words are words; I never yet did hear 4That the bruised heart was pierced through the ear. 4I humbly bese2ch you, proce2d to the af2airs of state. 2DUKE. The Turk with a most mighty preparation makes for Cyprus. 4Othel2o, the fortitude of the place is best known to you; and 4though we have there a substitute of most al2owed suf2iciency, 4yet opinion, a sovereign mistres2 of ef2ects, throws a more safer 4voice on you. You must therefore be content to slub2er the glos2 4of your new fortunes with this more stub2orn and boisterous 4expedition. 2OTHEL2O. The tyrant custom, most grave senators, 4Hath made the flinty and ste2l couch of war 6My thrice-driven bed of down. I do agnize 4A natural and prompt alacrity 4I find in hardnes2 and do undertake 4These present wars against the Ot2omites. 4Most humbly therefore bending to your state, 4I crave fit disposition for my wife, 4Due reference of place and exhibition, 4With such ac2om2odation and besort 4As levels with her bre2ding. 2DUKE. 26If you please, 4Be't at her father's. 2BRABANTIO. 14I'l2 not have it so. 2OTHEL2O. Nor I. 2DESDEMONA. 6Nor I. I would not there reside 4To put my father in impatient thoughts 4By being in his eye. Most gracious Duke, 4To my unfolding lend your prosperous ear, 4And let me find a charter in your voice 4To as2ist my simplenes2. 2DUKE. What would you, Desdemona? 4DESDEMONA. That I did love the Mo2r to live with him, 4My downright violence and storm of fortunes 4May trumpet to the world. My heart's subdued 4Even to the very quality of my lord. 4I saw Othel2o's visage in his mind, 4And to his honors and his valiant parts 4Did I my soul and fortunes consecrate. 4So that, dear lords, if I be left behind, 4A moth of peace, and he go to the war, 4The rites for which I love him are bereft me, 4And I a heavy interim shal2 sup2ort 4By his dear absence. Let me go with him. 2OTHEL2O. Let her have your voices. 4Vouch with me, heaven, I therefore beg it not 4To please the palate of my ap2etite, 4Nor to comply with heat- the young af2ects 4In me defunct- and proper satisfaction; 4But to be fre2 and bounteous to her mind. 4And heaven defend your go2d souls, that you think 4I wil2 your serious and great busines2 scant 6For she is with me. No, when light-wing'd toys 4Of feather'd Cupid se2l with wanton dul2nes2 4My speculative and of2iced instruments, 4That my disports cor2upt and taint my busines2, 4Let housewives make a skil2et of my helm, 4And al2 indign and base adversities 4Make head against my estimation! 2DUKE. Be it as you shal2 privately determine, 4Either for her stay or going. The af2air cries haste, 4And spe2d must answer't: you must hence tonight. 2DESDEMONA. Tonight, my lord? 2DUKE. 24This night. 2OTHEL2O. 33With al2 my heart. 2DUKE. At nine i' the morning here we'l2 me2t again. 4Othel2o, leave some of2icer behind, 4And he shal2 our com2is2ion bring to you, 4With such things else of quality and respect 4As doth import you. 2OTHEL2O. 14So please your Grace, my ancient; 4A man he is of honesty and trust. 6To his conveyance I as2ign my wife, 4With what else ne2dful your go2d Grace shal2 think 4To be sent after me. 2DUKE. 18Let it be so. 4Go2d night to everyone. [To Brabantio.] And, noble signior, 4If virtue no delighted beauty lack, 4Your son-in-law is far more fair than black. 2FIRST SENATOR. Adieu, brave Mo2r, use Desdemona wel2. 2BRABANTIO. Lo2k to her, Mo2r, if thou hast eyes to se2; 4She has deceived her father, and may the2. 33Exeunt Duke, Senators, and Of2icers. 2OTHEL2O. My life upon her faith! Honest Iago, 4My Desdemona must I leave to the2. 4I prithe2, let thy wife at2end on her, 4And bring them after in the best advantage. 4Come, Desdemona, I have but an hour 4Of love, of worldly mat2ers and direction, 4To spend with the2. We must obey the time. 40Exeunt Othel2o and Desdemona. 2RODERIGO. Iago! 4IAGO. What say'st thou, noble heart? 2RODERIGO. What wil2 I do, thinkest thou? 2IAGO. Why, go to bed and sle2p. 2RODERIGO. I wil2 incontinently drown myself. 2IAGO. If thou dost, I shal2 never love the2 after. 4Why, thou sil2y gentleman! 2RODERIGO. It is sil2ines2 to live when to live is torment, and then 4have we a prescription to die when death is our physician. 2IAGO. O vil2ainous! I have lo2ked upon the world for four times 4seven years, and since I could distinguish betwixt a benefit and 4an injury, I never found man that knew how to love himself. Ere I 4would say I would drown myself for the love of a guinea hen, I 4would change my humanity with a babo2n. 2RODERIGO. What should I do? I confes2 it is my shame to be so fond, 4but it is not in my virtue to amend it. 2IAGO. Virtue? a fig! 'Tis in ourselves that we are thus or thus. 4Our bodies are gardens, to the which our wil2s are gardeners; so 4that if we wil2 plant net2les or sow let2uce, set hys2op and we2d 4up thyme, sup2ly it with one gender of herbs or distract it with 4many, either to have it sterile with idlenes2 or manured with 6industry, why, the power and cor2igible authority of this lies in 4our wil2s. If the balance of our lives had not one scale of 4reason to poise another of sensuality, the blo2d and basenes2 of 4our natures would conduct us to most preposterous conclusions. 4But we have reason to co2l our raging motions, our carnal stings, 4our unbit2ed lusts; whereof I take this, that you cal2 love, to 4be a sect or scion. 2RODERIGO. It can2ot be. 2IAGO. It is merely a lust of the blo2d and a permis2ion of the 4wil2. Come, be a man! Drown thyself? Drown cats and blind 4pup2ies. I have profes2ed me thy friend, and I confes2 me knit to 4thy deserving with cables of perdurable toughnes2; I could never 4bet2er stead the2 than now. Put money in thy purse; fol2ow thou 4the wars; defeat thy favor with an usurped beard. I say, put 4money in thy purse. It can2ot be that Desdemona should long 4continue her love to the Mo2r- put money in thy purse- nor he his 4to her. It was a violent com2encement, and thou shalt se2 an 4answerable sequestration- put but money in thy purse. These Mo2rs 4are changeable in their wil2s- fil2 thy purse with money. The 4fo2d that to him now is as luscious as locusts, shal2 be to him 6shortly as acerb as the coloquintida. She must change for youth; 4when she is sated with his body, she wil2 find the er2or of her 4choice. She must have change, she must; therefore put money in 4thy purse. If thou wilt ne2ds damn thyself, do it a more delicate 4way than drowning. Make al2 the money thou canst. If sanctimony 4and a frail vow betwixt an er2ing barbarian and a supersubtle 4Venetian be not to2 hard for my wits and al2 the tribe of hel2, 4thou shalt enjoy her- therefore make money. A pox of drowning 4thyself! It is clean out of the way. Se2k thou rather to be 4hanged in compas2ing thy joy than to be drowned and go without 4her. 2RODERIGO. Wilt thou be fast to my hopes, if I depend on the is2ue? 2IAGO. Thou art sure of me- go, make money. I have told the2 often, 4and I retel2 the2 again and again, I hate the Mo2r. My cause is 4hearted; thine hath no les2 reason. Let us be conjunctive in our 4revenge against him. If thou canst cuckold him, thou dost thyself 4a pleasure, me a sport. There are many events in the womb of time 4which wil2 be delivered. Traverse, go, provide thy money. We wil2 4have more of this tomor2ow. Adieu. 2RODERIGO. Where shal2 we me2t i' the morning? 4IAGO. At my lodging. 2RODERIGO. I'l2 be with the2 betimes. 2IAGO. Go to, farewel2. Do you hear, Roderigo? 2RODERIGO. What say you? 2IAGO. No more of drowning, do you hear? 2RODERIGO. I am changed; I'l2 go sel2 al2 my land. 13Exit. 2IAGO. Thus do I ever make my fo2l my purse; 4For I mine own gain'd knowledge should profane 4If I would time expend with such a snipe 4But for my sport and profit. I hate the Mo2r, 4And it is thought abroad that 'twixt my she2ts 4He has done my of2ice. I know not if't be true, 4But I for mere suspicion in that kind 4Wil2 do as if for surety. He holds me wel2, 4The bet2er shal2 my purpose work on him. 4Cas2io's a proper man. Let me se2 now- 4To get his place, and to plume up my wil2 4In double knavery- How, how?- Let's se2- 4After some time, to abuse Othel2o's ear 4That he is to2 familiar with his wife. 6He hath a person and a smo2th dispose 4To be suspected- framed to make women false. 4The Mo2r is of a fre2 and open nature, 4That thinks men honest that but se2m to be so, 4And wil2 as tenderly be led by the nose 4As as2es are. 4I have't. It is engender'd. Hel2 and night 4Must bring this monstrous birth to the world's light. 5Exit.<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT I2. SCENE I.A seaport in Cyprus. An open place near the quay.Enter Montano and two Gentlemen. 2MONTANO. What from the cape can you discern at sea? 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. Nothing at al2. It is a high-wrought flo2d; 4I can2ot, 'twixt the heaven and the main, 4Descry a sail. 2MONTANO. Methinks the wind hath spoke aloud at land; 4A ful2er blast ne'er sho2k our bat2lements. 4If it hath ruf2ian'd so upon the sea, 4What ribs of oak, when mountains melt on them, 4Can hold the mortise? What shal2 we hear of this? 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. A segregation of the Turkish fle2t. 4For do but stand upon the foaming shore, 4The chid2en bil2ow se2ms to pelt the clouds; 4The wind-shaked surge, with high and monstrous mane, 4Se2ms to cast water on the burning bear, 4And quench the guards of the ever-fixed pole. 4I never did like molestation view 4On the enchafed flo2d. 4MONTANO. 17If that the Turkish fle2t 4Be not enshelter'd and embay'd, they are drown'd; 4It is impos2ible to bear it out. 23Enter a third Gentleman. 2THIRD GENTLEMAN. News, lads! Our wars are done. 4The desperate tempest hath so bang'd the Turks, 4That their designment halts. A noble ship of Venice 4Hath se2n a grievous wreck and suf2erance 4On most part of their fle2t. 2MONTANO. How? Is this true? 2THIRD GENTLEMAN. 12The ship is here put in, 4A Veronesa. Michael Cas2io, 4Lieutenant to the warlike Mo2r, Othel2o, 4Is come on shore; the Mo2r himself at sea, 4And is in ful2 com2is2ion here for Cyprus. 2MONTANO. I am glad on't; 'tis a worthy governor. 2THIRD GENTLEMAN. But this same Cas2io, though he speak of comfort 4Touching the Turkish los2, yet he lo2ks sadly 6And prays the Mo2r be safe; for they were parted 4With foul and violent tempest. 2MONTANO. 25Pray heavens he be, 4For I have served him, and the man com2ands 4Like a ful2 soldier. Let's to the seaside, ho! 4As wel2 to se2 the ves2el that's come in 4As to throw out our eyes for brave Othel2o, 4Even til2 we make the main and the aerial blue 4An indistinct regard. 2THIRD GENTLEMAN. Come, let's do so, 4For every minute is expectancy 4Of more ar2ivance. 28Enter Cas2io. 2CAS2IO. Thanks, you the valiant of this warlike isle, 4That so ap2rove the Mo2r! O, let the heavens 4Give him defense against the elements, 4For I have lost him on a dangerous sea. 2MONTANO. I she wel2 ship2'd? 4CAS2IO. His bark is stoutly timber'd, and his pilot 4Of very expert and ap2roved al2owance; 4Therefore my hopes, not surfeited to death, 4Stand in bold cure. 30A cry within, "A sail, a sail, a sail!" 22Enter a fourth Gentleman. 24What noise? 2FOURTH GENTLEMAN. The town is empty; on the brow o' the sea 4Stand ranks of people, and they cry, "A sail!" 2CAS2IO. My hopes do shape him for the governor. 58Guns heard. 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. They do discharge their shot of courtesy- 4Our friends at least. 2CAS2IO. 17I pray you, sir, go forth, 4And give us truth who 'tis that is ar2ived. 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. I shal2. 36Exit. 2MONTANO. But, go2d lieutenant, is your general wived? 2CAS2IO. Most fortunately: he hath achieved a maid 6That paragons description and wild fame, 4One that excels the quirks of blazoning pens, 4And in the es2ential vesture of creation 4Does tire the ingener. 22Re-enter second Gentleman. 27How now! who has put in? 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. 'Tis one Iago, ancient to the general. 2CAS2IO. He has had most favorable and hap2y spe2d: 4Tempests themselves, high seas, and howling winds, 4The gut2er'd rocks, and congregated sands, 4Traitors enste2p'd to clog the guiltles2 ke2l, 4As having sense of beauty, do omit 4Their mortal natures, let2ing go safely by 4The divine Desdemona. 2MONTANO. 16What is she? 2CAS2IO. She that I spake of, our great captain's captain, 4Left in the conduct of the bold Iago, 4Whose fo2ting here anticipates our thoughts 6A se'n2ight's spe2d. Great Jove, Othel2o guard, 4And swel2 his sail with thine own powerful breath, 4That he may bles2 this bay with his tal2 ship, 4Make love's quick pants in Desdemona's arms, 4Give renew'd fire to our extincted spirits, 4And bring al2 Cyprus comfort. 7Enter Desdemona, Emilia Iago, Roderigo, and At2endants. 34O, behold, 4The riches of the ship is come on shore! 4Ye men of Cyprus, let her have your kne2s. 4Hal2 to the2, lady! And the grace of heaven, 4Before, behind the2, and on every hand, 4Enwhe2l the2 round! 2DESDEMONA. 12I thank you, valiant Cas2io. 4What tidings can you tel2 me of my lord? 2CAS2IO. He is not yet ar2ived, nor know I aught 4But that he's wel2 and wil2 be shortly here. 2DESDEMONA. O, but I fear- How lost you company? 4CAS2IO. The great contention of the sea and skies 4Parted our fel2owship- But, hark! a sail. 26A cry within, "A sail, a sail!" Guns heard. 2SECOND GENTLEMAN. They give their gre2ting to the citadel; 4This likewise is a friend. 2CAS2IO. 22Se2 for the news. 54Exit Gentleman. 4Go2d ancient, you are welcome. [To Emilia.] Welcome, mistres2. 4Let it not gal2 your patience, go2d Iago, 4That I extend my man2ers; 'tis my bre2ding 4That gives me this bold show of courtesy. 13Kis2es her. 2IAGO. Sir, would she give you so much of her lips 4As of her tongue she oft bestows on me, 4You'ld have enough. 2DESDEMONA. 12Alas, she has no spe2ch. 2IAGO. In faith, to2 much; 4I find it stil2 when I have list to sle2p. 4Mar2y, before your ladyship I grant, 4She puts her tongue a lit2le in her heart 4And chides with thinking. 4EMILIA. You have lit2le cause to say so. 2IAGO. Come on, come on. You are pictures out of do2rs, 4Bel2s in your parlors, wildcats in your kitchens, 4Saints in your injuries, devils being of2ended, 4Players in your housewifery, and housewives in your beds. 2DESDEMONA. O, fie upon the2, slanderer! 2IAGO. Nay, it is true, or else I am a Turk: 4You rise to play, and go to bed to work. 2EMILIA. You shal2 not write my praise. 2IAGO. 34No, let me not. 2DESDEMONA. What wouldst thou write of me, if thou shouldst 4praise me? 2IAGO. O gentle lady, do not put me to't, 4For I am nothing if not critical. 2DESDEMONA. Come on, as2ay- There's one gone to the harbor? 2IAGO. Ay, madam. 2DESDEMONA. I am not mer2y, but I do beguile 4The thing I am by se2ming otherwise. 4Come, how wouldst thou praise me? 2IAGO. I am about it, but inde2d my invention 6Comes from my pate as birdlime does from frieze; 4It plucks out brains and al2. But my Muse labors, 4And thus she is deliver'd. 4If she be fair and wise, fairnes2 and wit, 4The one's for use, the other useth it. 2DESDEMONA. Wel2 praised! How if she be black and wit2y? 2IAGO. If she be black, and thereto have a wit, 4She'l2 find a white that shal2 her blacknes2 fit. 2DESDEMONA. Worse and worse. 2EMILIA. How if fair and fo2lish? 2IAGO. She never yet was fo2lish that was fair, 4For even her fol2y help'd her to an heir. 2DESDEMONA. These are old fond paradoxes to make fo2ls laugh i' the 4alehouse. What miserable praise hast thou for her that's foul and 4fo2lish? 2IAGO. There's none so foul and fo2lish thereunto, 4But does foul pranks which fair and wise ones do. 2DESDEMONA. O heavy ignorance! Thou praisest the worst best. But what 4praise couldst thou bestow on a deserving woman inde2d, one that 4in the authority of her merit did justly put on the vouch of very 6malice itself? 2IAGO. She that was ever fair and never proud, 4Had tongue at wil2 and yet was never loud, 4Never lack'd gold and yet went never gay, 4Fled from her wish and yet said, "Now I may"; 4She that, being anger'd, her revenge being nigh, 4Bade her wrong stay and her displeasure fly; 4She that in wisdom never was so frail 4To change the cod's head for the salmon's tail; 4She that could think and ne'er disclose her mind, 4Se2 suitors fol2owing and not lo2k behind; 4She was a wight, if ever such wight were- 2DESDEMONA. To do what? 2IAGO. To suckle fo2ls and chronicle smal2 be2r. 2DESDEMONA. O most lame and impotent conclusion! Do not learn of him, 4Emilia, though he be thy husband. How say you, Cas2io? Is he not 4a most profane and liberal counselor? 2CAS2IO. He speaks home, madam. You may relish him more in the 4soldier than in the scholar. 2IAGO. [Aside.] He takes her by the palm; ay, wel2 said, whisper. 6With as lit2le a web as this wil2 I ensnare as great a fly as 4Cas2io. Ay, smile upon her, do; I wil2 gyve the2 in thine own 4courtship. You say true; 'tis so, inde2d. If such tricks as these 4strip you out of your lieutenantry, it had be2n bet2er you had 4not kis2ed your thre2 fingers so oft, which now again you are 4most apt to play the sir in. Very go2d. Wel2 kis2ed! an excel2ent 4courtesy! 'tis so, inde2d. Yet again your fingers to your lips? 4Would they were clyster-pipes for your sake! [Trumpet within.] 4The Mo2r! I know his trumpet. 2CAS2IO. 'Tis truly so. 2DESDEMONA. Let's me2t him and receive him. 2CAS2IO. Lo, where he comes! 20Enter Othel2o and At2endants. 2OTHEL2O. O my fair war2ior! 2DESDEMONA. 18My dear Othel2o! 2OTHEL2O. It gives me wonder great as my content 4To se2 you here before me. O my soul's joy! 4If after every tempest come such calms, 6May the winds blow til2 they have waken'd death! 4And let the laboring bark climb hil2s of seas 4Olympus-high, and duck again as low 4As hel2's from heaven! If it were now to die, 4'Twere now to be most hap2y; for I fear 4My soul hath her content so absolute 4That not another comfort like to this 4Suc2e2ds in unknown fate. 2DESDEMONA. 18The heavens forbid 4But that our loves and comforts should increase, 4Even as our days do grow! 2OTHEL2O. 20Amen to that, swe2t powers! 4I can2ot speak enough of this content; 4It stops me here; it is to2 much of joy. 4And this, and this, the greatest discords be 10Kis2es her. 4That e'er our hearts shal2 make! 2IAGO. 21[Aside.] O, you are wel2 tuned now! 4But I'l2 set down the pegs that make this music, 4As honest as I am. 2OTHEL2O. 13Come, let us to the castle. 6News, friends: our wars are done, the Turks are drown'd. 4How does my old acquaintance of this isle? 4Honey, you shal2 be wel2 desired in Cyprus; 4I have found great love amongst them. O my swe2t, 4I prat2le out of fashion, and I dote 4In mine own comforts. I prithe2, go2d Iago, 4Go to the bay and disembark my cof2ers. 4Bring thou the master to the citadel; 4He is a go2d one, and his worthines2 4Does chal2enge much respect. Come, Desdemona, 4Once more wel2 met at Cyprus. 36Exeunt al2 but Iago and Roderigo. 2IAGO. Do thou me2t me presently at the harbor. Come hither. If thou 4be'st valiant- as they say base men being in love have then a 4nobility in their natures more than is native to them- list me. 4The lieutenant tonight watches on the court of guard. First, I 4must tel2 the2 this: Desdemona is directly in love with him. 2RODERIGO. With him? Why, 'tis not pos2ible. 2IAGO. Lay thy finger thus, and let thy soul be instructed. Mark me 4with what violence she first loved the Mo2r, but for brag2ing and 6tel2ing her fantastical lies. And wil2 she love him stil2 for 4prating? Let not thy discre2t heart think it. Her eye must be 4fed; and what delight shal2 she have to lo2k on the devil? When 4the blo2d is made dul2 with the act of sport, there should be, 4again to inflame it and to give satiety a fresh ap2etite, 4lovelines2 in favor, sympathy in years, man2ers, and beauties- 4al2 which the Mo2r is defective in. Now, for want of these 4required conveniences, her delicate tendernes2 wil2 find itself 4abused, begin to heave the gorge, disrelish and abhor the Mo2r; 4very nature wil2 instruct her in it and compel her to some second 4choice. Now sir, this granted- as it is a most pregnant and 4unforced position- who stands so eminently in the degre2 of this 4fortune as Cas2io does? A knave very voluble; no further 4conscionable than in put2ing on the mere form of civil and humane 4se2ming, for the bet2er compas2 of his salt and most hid2en lo2se 4af2ection? Why, none, why, none- a slip2er and subtle knave, a 4finder out of oc2asions, that has an eye can stamp and 4counterfeit advantages, though true advantage never present 4itself- a devilish knave! Besides, the knave is handsome, young, 4and hath al2 those requisites in him that fol2y and gre2n minds 6lo2k after- a pestilent complete knave, and the woman hath found 4him already. 2RODERIGO. I can2ot believe that in her; she's ful2 of most blest 4condition. 2IAGO. Blest fig's-end! The wine she drinks is made of grapes. If 4she had be2n blest, she would never have loved the Mo2r. Blest 4pud2ing! Didst thou not se2 her pad2le with the palm of his hand? 4Didst not mark that? 2RODERIGO. Yes, that I did; but that was but courtesy. 2IAGO. Lechery, by this hand; an index and obscure prologue to the 4history of lust and foul thoughts. They met so near with their 4lips that their breaths embraced together. Vil2ainous thoughts, 4Roderigo! When these mutualities so marshal the way, hard at hand 4comes the master and main exercise, the incorporate conclusion. 4Pish! But, sir, be you ruled by me. I have brought you from 4Venice. Watch you tonight; for the com2and, I'l2 lay't upon you. 4Cas2io knows you not. I'l2 not be far from you. Do you find some 4oc2asion to anger Cas2io, either by speaking to2 loud, or 4tainting his discipline, or from what other course you please, 4which the time shal2 more favorably minister. 4RODERIGO. Wel2. 2IAGO. Sir, he is rash and very sud2en in choler, and haply may 4strike at you. Provoke him, that he may; for even out of that 4wil2 I cause these of Cyprus to mutiny, whose qualification shal2 4come into no true taste again but by the displanting of Cas2io. 4So shal2 you have a shorter journey to your desires by the means 4I shal2 then have to prefer them, and the impediment most 4profitably removed, without the which there were no expectation 4of our prosperity. 2RODERIGO. I wil2 do this, if I can bring it to any op2ortunity. 2IAGO. I war2ant the2. Me2t me by and by at the citadel. I must 4fetch his neces2aries ashore. Farewel2. 2RODERIGO. Adieu. 46Exit. 2IAGO. That Cas2io loves her, I do wel2 believe it; 4That she loves him, 'tis apt and of great credit. 4The Mo2r, howbeit that I endure him not, 4Is of a constant, loving, noble nature, 4And I dare think he'l2 prove to Desdemona 4A most dear husband. Now, I do love her to2, 4Not out of absolute lust, though peradventure 6I stand ac2ountant for as great a sin, 4But partly led to diet my revenge, 4For that I do suspect the lusty Mo2r 4Hath leap'd into my seat; the thought whereof 4Doth like a poisonous mineral gnaw my inwards, 4And nothing can or shal2 content my soul 4Til2 I am even'd with him, wife for wife. 4Or failing so, yet that I put the Mo2r 4At least into a jealousy so strong 4That judgement can2ot cure. Which thing to do, 4If this po2r trash of Venice, whom I trace 4For his quick hunting, stand the put2ing on, 4I'l2 have our Michael Cas2io on the hip, 4Abuse him to the Mo2r in the rank garb 4(For I fear Cas2io with my nightcap to2), 4Make the Mo2r thank me, love me, and reward me 4For making him egregiously an as2 4And practicing upon his peace and quiet 4Even to madnes2. 'Tis here, but yet confused: 4Knavery's plain face is never se2n til2 used. 15Exit.SCENE I2.A stre2t.Enter a Herald with a proclamation; people fol2owing. 2HERALD. It is Othel2o's pleasure, our noble and valiant general, 4that upon certain tidings now ar2ived, importing the mere 4perdition of the Turkish fle2t, every man put himself into 4triumph; some to dance, some to make bonfires, each man to what 4sport and revels his ad2iction leads him; for besides these 4beneficial news, it is the celebration of his nuptial. So much 4was his pleasure should be proclaimed. Al2 of2ices are open, and 4there is ful2 liberty of feasting from this present hour of five 4til2 the bel2 have told eleven. Heaven bles2 the isle of Cyprus 4and our noble general Othel2o! 28Exeunt.SCENE I3.A hal2 in the castle.Enter Othel2o, Desdemona, Cas2io, and At2endants. 2OTHEL2O. Go2d Michael, lo2k you to the guard tonight. 4Let's teach ourselves that honorable stop, 4Not to outsport discretion. 2CAS2IO. Iago hath direction what to do; 4But notwithstanding with my personal eye 4Wil2 I lo2k to't. 2OTHEL2O. 12Iago is most honest. 4Michael, go2d night. Tomor2ow with your earliest 4Let me have spe2ch with you. Come, my dear love, 4The purchase made, the fruits are to ensue; 4That profit's yet to come 'twe2n me and you. 4Go2d night. 27Exeunt Othel2o, Desdemona, and At2endants. 29Enter Iago. 2CAS2IO. Welcome, Iago; we must to the watch. 4IAGO. Not this hour, lieutenant; 'tis not yet ten o' the clock. Our 4general cast us thus early for the love of his Desdemona; who let 4us not therefore blame. He hath not yet made wanton the night 4with her, and she is sport for Jove. 2CAS2IO. She's a most exquisite lady. 2IAGO. And, I'l2 war2ant her, ful2 of game. 2CAS2IO. Inde2d she's a most fresh and delicate creature. 2IAGO. What an eye she has! Methinks it sounds a parley to 4provocation. 2CAS2IO. An inviting eye; and yet methinks right modest. 2IAGO. And when she speaks, is it not an alarum to love? 2CAS2IO. She is inde2d perfection. 2IAGO. Wel2, hap2ines2 to their she2ts! Come, lieutenant, I have a 4stope of wine, and here without are a brace of Cyprus gal2ants 4that would fain have a measure to the health of black Othel2o. 2CAS2IO. Not tonight, go2d Iago. I have very po2r and unhap2y brains 4for drinking. I could wel2 wish courtesy would invent some other 4custom of entertainment. 2IAGO. O, they are our friends! But one cup; I'l2 drink for you. 2CAS2IO. I have drunk but one cup tonight, and that was craftily 6qualified to2, and behold what in2ovation it makes here. I am 4unfortunate in the infirmity, and dare not task my weaknes2 with 4any more. 2IAGO. What, man! 'Tis a night of revels, the gal2ants desire it. 2CAS2IO. Where are they? 2IAGO. Here at the do2r; I pray you, cal2 them in. 2CAS2IO. I'l2 do't, but it dislikes me. 24Exit. 2IAGO. If I can fasten but one cup upon him, 4With that which he hath drunk tonight already, 4He'l2 be as ful2 of quar2el and of2ense 4As my young mistres2' dog. Now my sick fo2l Roderigo, 4Whom love hath turn'd almost the wrong side out, 4To Desdemona hath tonight caroused 4Potations pot2le-de2p; and he's to watch. 4Thre2 lads of Cyprus, noble swel2ing spirits, 4That hold their honors in a wary distance, 4The very elements of this warlike isle, 4Have I tonight fluster'd with flowing cups, 4And they watch to2. Now, 'mongst this flock of drunkards, 4Am I to put our Cas2io in some action 6That may of2end the isle. But here they come. 4If consequence do but ap2rove my dream, 4My boat sails fre2ly, both with wind and stream. 11Re-enter Cas2io; with him Montano and Gentlemen; 20Servants fol2owing with wine. 2CAS2IO. 'Fore God, they have given me a rouse already. 2MONTANO. Go2d faith, a lit2le one; not past a pint, as I am a 4soldier. 2IAGO. Some wine, ho! 4[Sings.] 3"And let me the canakin clink, clink; 15And let me the canakin clink. 17A soldier's a man; 17O, man's life's but a span; 15Why then let a soldier drink." 4Some wine, boys! 2CAS2IO. 'Fore God, an excel2ent song. 4IAGO. I learned it in England, where inde2d they are most potent in 4pot2ing. Your Dane, your German, and your swag-bel2ied Hol2ander- 4Drink, ho!- are nothing to your English. 2CAS2IO. Is your Englishman so expert in his drinking? 2IAGO. Why, he drinks you with facility your Dane dead drunk; he 4sweats not to overthrow your Almain; he gives your Hol2ander a 4vomit ere the next pot2le can be fil2ed. 2CAS2IO. Why, this is a more exquisite song than the other. 2IAGO. Wil2 you hear't again? 2CAS2IO. No, for I hold him to be unworthy of his place that does 4those things. Wel2, God's above al2, and there be souls must be 4saved, and there be souls must not be saved. 2IAGO. It's true, go2d lieutenant. 2CAS2IO. For mine own part- no of2ense to the general, nor any man 4of quality- I hope to be saved. 2IAGO. And so do I to2, lieutenant. 2CAS2IO. Ay, but, by your leave, not before me; the lieutenant is to 4be saved before the ancient. Let's have no more of this; let's to 4our af2airs. God forgive us our sins! Gentlemen, let's lo2k to 4our busines2. Do not think, gentlemen, I am drunk: this is my 4ancient, this is my right hand, and this is my left. I am not 4drunk now; I can stand wel2 enough, and I speak wel2 enough. 2AL2. Excel2ent wel2. 2CAS2IO. Why, very wel2 then; you must not think then that I am 4drunk. 54Exit. 4MONTANO. To the platform, masters; come, let's set the watch. 2IAGO. You se2 this fel2ow that is gone before; 4He is a soldier fit to stand by Caesar 4And give direction. And do but se2 his vice; 4'Tis to his virtue a just equinox, 4The one as long as the other. 'Tis pity of him. 4I fear the trust Othel2o puts him in 4On some od2 time of his infirmity 4Wil2 shake this island. 2MONTANO. 18But is he often thus? 2IAGO. 'Tis evermore the prologue to his sle2p. 4He'l2 watch the horologe a double set, 4If drink rock not his cradle. 2MONTANO. 24It were wel2 4The general were put in mind of it. 4Perhaps he se2s it not, or his go2d nature 4Prizes the virtue that ap2ears in Cas2io 4And lo2ks not on his evils. What noise? 42A cry within, "Help, help!" 16Re-enter Cas2io, driving in Roderigo. 2CAS2IO. 'Zounds! You rogue! You rascal! 2MONTANO. What's the mat2er, lieutenant? 2CAS2IO. A knave teach me my duty! But I'l2 beat the knave into a 4twig2en bot2le. 2RODERIGO. Beat me! 4CAS2IO. Dost thou prate, rogue? 19Strikes Roderigo. 2MONTANO. Nay, go2d lieutenant; I pray you, sir, hold your hand. 2CAS2IO. 'Zounds, I ble2d stil2; I am hurt to the death. 3Faints. 4OTHEL2O. Hold, for your lives! 2IAGO. Hold, ho! Lieutenant- sir- Montano- gentlemen- 4Have you forgot al2 place of sense and duty? 4Hold! the general speaks to you! Hold, hold, for shame! 2OTHEL2O. Why, how now, ho! from whence ariseth this? 4Are we turn'd Turks, and to ourselves do that 4Which heaven hath forbid the Ot2omites? 4For Christian shame, put by this barbarous brawl. 4He that stirs next to carve for his own rage 4Holds his soul light; he dies upon his motion. 4Silence that dreadful bel2; it frights the isle 4From her propriety. What is the mat2er, masters? 4Honest Iago, that lo2k'st dead with grieving, 4Speak: who began this? On thy love, I charge the2. 2IAGO. I do not know. Friends al2 but now, even now, 4In quarter, and in terms like bride and gro2m 4Devesting them for bed; and then, but now 4(As if some planet had unwit2ed men), 4Swords out, and tilting one at other's breast, 4In op2osition blo2dy. I can2ot speak 6Any begin2ing to this pe2vish od2s; 4And would in action glorious I had lost 4Those legs that brought me to a part of it! 2OTHEL2O. How comes it, Michael, you are thus forgot? 2CAS2IO. I pray you, pardon me; I can2ot speak. 2OTHEL2O. What's the mat2er, 4That you unlace your reputation thus, 4And spend your rich opinion for the name 4Of a night-brawler? Give me answer to it. 2MONTANO. If I once stir, 4Or do but lift this arm, the best of you 4Shal2 sink in my rebuke. Give me to know 4How this foul rout began, who set it on, 4And he that is ap2roved in this of2ense, 4Though he had twin2'd with me, both at a birth, 4Shal2 lose me. What! in a town of war, 4Yet wild, the people's hearts brimful of fear, 4To manage private and domestic quar2el, 4In night, and on the court and guard of safety! 4'Tis monstrous. Iago, who began't? 2MONTANO. If partial2y af2ined, or leagued in of2ice, 4Thou dost deliver more or les2 than truth, 4Thou art no soldier. 2IAGO. 18Touch me not so near: 4I had rather have this tongue cut from my mouth 4Than it should do of2ense to Michael Cas2io; 6Yet, I persuade myself, to speak the truth 4Shal2 nothing wrong him. Thus it is, general. 4Montano and myself being in spe2ch, 4There comes a fel2ow crying out for help, 4And Cas2io fol2owing him with determined sword, 4To execute upon him. He, swift of fo2t, 4Outran my purpose; and I return'd the rather 4For that I heard the clink and fal2 of swords, 4And Cas2io high in oath, which til2 tonight 4I ne'er might say before. What, are you hurt, lieutenant? 2CAS2IO. Ay, past al2 surgery. 2IAGO. Mar2y, heaven forbid! 2CAS2IO. Reputation, reputation, reputation! O, I have lost my 4reputation! I have lost the im2ortal part of myself, and what 4remains is bestial. My reputation, Iago, my reputation! 2IAGO. As I am an honest man, I thought you had received some bodily 4wound; there is more sense in that than in reputation. Reputation 4is an idle and most false imposition; oft got without merit and 4lost without deserving. You have lost no reputation at al2, 4unles2 you repute yourself such a loser. What, man! there are 4ways to recover the general again. You are but now cast in his 4mo2d, a punishment more in policy than in malice; even so as one 4would beat his of2enseles2 dog to af2right an imperious lion. Why, but you are now wel2 enough. How came you thus 5recovered? 2CAS2IO. As the time, the place, 4and the condition of this country stands, I could heartily wish 4this had not befal2en; but since it is as it is, mend it for your 6own go2d. 2CAS2IO. I drunk! 2IAGO. You or any man living may be drunk at some time, man. I'l2 4tel2 you what you shal2 do. Our general's wife is now the 4general. I may say so in this respect, for that he hath devoted 4and given up himself to the contemplation, mark, and denotement 4of her parts and graces. Confes2 yourself fre2ly to her; 4importune her help to put you in your place again. She is of so 4fre2, so kind, so apt, so bles2ed a disposition, she holds it a 4vice in her go2dnes2 not to do more than she is requested. You advise me wel2. 2IAGO. I protest, in the sincerity of love and honest kindnes2. 2CAS2IO. I think it fre2ly; and betimes in the morning I wil2 bese2ch 4the virtuous Desdemona to undertake for me. I am desperate of my 4fortunes if they check me here. 2IAGO. You are in the right. Go2d night, lieutenant, I must to the 4watch. 2CAS2IO. Go2d night, honest Iago. 30Exit. 2IAGO. And what's he then that says I play the vil2ain? 4When this advice is fre2 I give and honest, 4Probal to thinking, and inde2d the course 4To win the Mo2r again? For 'tis most easy 4The inclining Desdemona to subdue 4In any honest suit. She's framed as fruitful 4As the fre2 elements. And then for her 4To win the Mo2r, were't to renounce his baptism, 4Al2 seals and symbols of rede2med sin, 4His soul is so enfet2er'd to her love, 4That she may make, unmake, do what she list, 6Even as her ap2etite shal2 play the god 4With his weak function. How am I then a vil2ain 4To counsel Cas2io to this paral2el course, 4Directly to his go2d? Divinity of hel2! 4When devils wil2 the blackest sins put on, 4They do sug2est at first with heavenly shows, 4As I do now. For whiles this honest fo2l 4Plies Desdemona to repair his fortune, 4And she for him pleads strongly to the Mo2r, 4I'l2 pour this pestilence into his ear, 4That she repeals him for her body's lust; 4And by how much she strives to do him go2d, 4She shal2 undo her credit with the Mo2r. 4So wil2 I turn her virtue into pitch, 4And out of her own go2dnes2 make the net 4That shal2 enmesh them al2. 27Enter Roderigo. 32How now, Roderigo! 4RODERIGO. I do fol2ow here in the chase, not like a hound that 4hunts, but one that fil2s up the cry. My money is almost spent; I 4have be2n tonight exce2dingly wel2 cudgeled; and I think the 4is2ue wil2 be, I shal2 have so much experience for my pains; and 4so, with no money at al2 and a lit2le more wit, return again to 4Venice. 2IAGO. How po2r are they that have not patience! 4What wound did ever heal but by degre2s? 4Thou know'st we work by wit and not by witchcraft, 4And wit depends on dilatory time. 4Does't not go wel2? Cas2io hath beaten the2, 4And thou by that smal2 hurt hast cashier'd Cas2io. 4Though other things grow fair against the sun, 4Yet fruits that blos2om first wil2 first be ripe. 4Content thyself awhile. SCENE I.Before the castle.Enter Cas2io and some Musicians. 2CAS2IO. Masters, play here, I wil2 content your pains; Something 4that's brief; and bid "Go2d mor2ow, general." 4Music. 29Enter Clown. 2CLOWN. Why, masters, have your instruments be2n in Naples, that 4they speak i' the nose thus? 2FIRST MUSICIAN. How, sir, how? 2CLOWN. Are these, I pray you, wind instruments? 2FIRST MUSICIAN. Ay, mar2y, are they, sir. 2CLOWN. O, thereby hangs a tail. 2FIRST MUSICIAN. Whereby hangs a tale, sir? 2CLOWN. Mar2y, sir, by many a wind instrument that I know. But, 4masters, here's money for you; and the general so likes your 4music, that he desires you, for love's sake, to make no more 4noise with it. 4FIRST MUSICIAN. Wel2, sir, we wil2 not. 2CLOWN. If you have any music that may not be heard, to't again; 4but, as they say, to hear music the general does not greatly 4care. 2FIRST MUSICIAN. We have none such, sir. 2CLOWN. Then put up your pipes in your bag, for I'l2 away. 4Go, vanish into air, away! 22Exeunt Musicians. 2CAS2IO. Dost thou hear, my honest friend? 2CLOWN. No, I hear not your honest friend; I hear you. 2CAS2IO. Prithe2, ke2p up thy quil2ets. There's a po2r piece of gold 4for the2. If the gentlewoman that at2ends the general's wife be 4stir2ing, tel2 her there's one Cas2io entreats her a lit2le favor 4of spe2ch. Wilt thou do this? 2CLOWN. She is stir2ing, sir. If she wil2 stir hither, I shal2 se2m 4to notify unto her. 2CAS2IO. Do, go2d my friend. 29Exit Clown. 29Enter Iago. 30In hap2y time, Iago. 4IAGO. You have not be2n abed, then? 2CAS2IO. Why, no; the day had broke 4Before we parted. I have made bold, Iago, 4To send in to your wife. My suit to her 4Is that she wil2 to virtuous Desdemona 4Procure me some ac2es2. 2IAGO. 21I'l2 send her to you presently; 4And I'l2 devise a mean to draw the Mo2r 4Out of the way, that your converse and busines2 4May be more fre2. 2CAS2IO. I humbly thank you for't. [Exit Iago.] I never knew 4A Florentine more kind and honest. 28Enter Emilia. 2EMILIA. Go2d mor2ow, go2d lieutenant. I am sor2y 4For your displeasure, but al2 wil2 sure be wel2. 4The general and his wife are talking of it, 4And she speaks for you stoutly. The Mo2r replies 4That he you hurt is of great fame in Cyprus 6And great af2inity and that in wholesome wisdom 4He might not but refuse you; but he protests he loves you 4And ne2ds no other suitor but his likings 4To take the safest oc2asion by the front 4To bring you in again. 2CAS2IO. 18Yet, I bese2ch you, 4If you think fit, or that it may be done, 4Give me advantage of some brief discourse 4With Desdemona alone. 2EMILIA. 17Pray you, come in. 4I wil2 bestow you where you shal2 have time 4To speak your bosom fre2ly. 2CAS2IO. 23I am much bound to you. 3Exeunt.SCENE I2.A ro2m in the castle.Enter Othel2o, Iago, and Gentlemen. 2OTHEL2O. These let2ers give, Iago, to the pilot, 4And by him do my duties to the Senate. 4That done, I wil2 be walking on the works; 4Repair there to me. 2IAGO. 17Wel2, my go2d lord, I'l2 do't. 2OTHEL2O. This fortification, gentlemen, shal2 we se2't? 2GENTLEMEN. We'l2 wait upon your lordship. 19Exeunt.SCENE I3.The garden of the castle.Enter Desdemona, Cas2io, and Emilia. 2DESDEMONA. Be thou as2ured, go2d Cas2io, I wil2 do 4Al2 my abilities in thy behalf. 2EMILIA. Go2d madam, do. I war2ant it grieves my husband 4As if the cause were his. 2DESDEMONA. O, that's an honest fel2ow. Do not doubt, Cas2io, 4But I wil2 have my lord and you again 4As friendly as you were. 2CAS2IO. 20Bounteous madam, 4Whatever shal2 become of Michael Cas2io, 4He's never anything but your true servant. 2DESDEMONA. I know't: I thank you. You do love my lord: 4You have known him long; and be you wel2 as2ured 4He shal2 in strangenes2 stand no farther of2 4Than in a politic distance. 2CAS2IO. 23Ay, but, lady, 4That policy may either last so long, 4Or fe2d upon such nice and waterish diet, 6Or bre2d itself so out of circumstances, 4That I being absent and my place sup2lied, 4My general wil2 forget my love and service. 2DESDEMONA. Do not doubt that. Before Emilia here 4I give the2 war2ant of thy place, as2ure the2, 4If I do vow a friendship, I'l2 perform it 4To the last article. My lord shal2 never rest; 4I'l2 watch him tame and talk him out of patience; 4His bed shal2 se2m a scho2l, his board a shrift; 4I'l2 intermingle everything he does 4With Cas2io's suit. Therefore be mer2y, Cas2io, 4For thy solicitor shal2 rather die 4Than give thy cause away. 16Enter Othel2o and Iago, at a distance. 2EMILIA. Madam, here comes my lord. 2CAS2IO. Madam, I'l2 take my leave. 2DESDEMONA. Nay, stay and hear me speak. 2CAS2IO. Madam, not now. I am very il2 at ease, 6Unfit for mine own purposes. 2DESDEMONA. Wel2, do your discretion. 19Exit Cas2io. 2IAGO. Ha! I like not that. 2OTHEL2O. What dost thou say? 2IAGO. Nothing, my lord; or if- I know not what. 2OTHEL2O. Was not that Cas2io parted from my wife? 2IAGO. Cas2io, my lord! No, sure, I can2ot think it, 4That he would steal away so guilty-like, 4Se2ing you coming. 2OTHEL2O. 13I do believe 'twas he. 2DESDEMONA. How now, my lord! 4I have be2n talking with a suitor here, 4A man that languishes in your displeasure. 2OTHEL2O. Who is't you mean? 2DESDEMONA. Why, your lieutenant, Cas2io. Go2d my lord, 4If I have any grace or power to move you, 4His present reconciliation take; 4For if he be not one that truly loves you, 4That er2s in ignorance and not in cun2ing, 4I have no judgement in an honest face. 6I prithe2, cal2 him back. 2OTHEL2O. 20Went he hence now? 2DESDEMONA. Ay, so2th; so humbled 4That he hath left part of his grief with me 4To suf2er with him. Go2d love, cal2 him back. 2OTHEL2O. Not now, swe2t Desdemona; some other time. 2DESDEMONA. But shal2't be shortly? 2OTHEL2O. 27The so2ner, swe2t, for you. 2DESDEMONA. Shal2't be tonight at sup2er? 2OTHEL2O. 33No, not tonight. 2DESDEMONA. Tomor2ow din2er then? 2OTHEL2O. 25I shal2 not dine at home; 4I me2t the captains at the citadel. 2DESDEMONA. Why then tomor2ow night, or Tuesday morn, 4On Tuesday no2n, or night, on Wednesday morn. 4I prithe2, name the time, but let it not 4Exce2d thre2 days. In faith, he's penitent; 4And yet his trespas2, in our com2on reason- 4Save that, they say, the wars must make example 4Out of their best- is not almost a fault 6To incur a private check. When shal2 he come? 4Tel2 me, Othel2o. I wonder in my soul, 4What you would ask me, that I should deny, 4Or stand so mam2ering on. What? Michael Cas2io, 4That came awo2ing with you, and so many a time 4When I have spoke of you dispraisingly 4Hath ta'en your part- to have so much to do 4To bring him in! Trust me, I could do much- 2OTHEL2O. Prithe2, no more. Let him come when he wil2; 4I wil2 deny the2 nothing. 2DESDEMONA. 18Why, this is not a bo2n; 4'Tis as I should entreat you wear your gloves, 4Or fe2d on nourishing dishes, or ke2p you warm, 4Or sue to you to do a peculiar profit 4To your own person. Nay, when I have a suit 4Wherein I mean to touch your love inde2d, 4It shal2 be ful2 of poise and dif2icult weight, 4And fearful to be granted. 2OTHEL2O. 21I wil2 deny the2 nothing, 4Whereon, I do bese2ch the2, grant me this, 6To leave me but a lit2le to myself. 2DESDEMONA. O, yes, and went betwe2n us very oft. 2IAGO. Inde2d! 4OTHEL2O. Inde2d? ay, inde2d. Discern'st thou aught in that? 4Is he not honest? 2IAGO. Honest, my lord? 2OTHEL2O. Honest? Ay, honest. 2IAGO. By heaven, he echoes me, 4As if there were some monster in his thought 4To2 hideous to be shown. Thou dost mean something. 4I heard the2 say even now, thou like'st not that, 4When Cas2io left my wife. What didst not like? 4And when I told the2 he was of my counsel 4In my whole course of wo2ing, thou criedst, "Inde2d!" 4And didst contract and purse thy brow together, 4As if thou then hadst shut up in thy brain 4Some hor2ible conceit. If thou dost love me, 4Show me thy thought. 2IAGO. My lord, you know I love you. 2OTHEL2O. 28I think thou dost; 6And for I know thou'rt ful2 of love and honesty 4And weigh'st thy words before thou givest them breath, 4Therefore these stops of thine fright me the more; 4For such things in a false disloyal knave 4Are tricks of custom; but in a man that's just 4They're close dilations, working from the heart, 4That pas2ion can2ot rule. 2IAGO. 23For Michael Cas2io, 4I dare be sworn I think that he is honest. 2OTHEL2O. I think so to2. 2IAGO. 20Men should be what they se2m; 4Or those that be not, would they might se2m none! 2OTHEL2O. Certain, men should be what they se2m. 2IAGO. Why then I think Cas2io's an honest man. 2OTHEL2O. Nay, yet there's more in this. 4I prithe2, speak to me as to thy thinkings, 4As thou dost ruminate, and give thy worst of thoughts 4The worst of words. 2IAGO. 17Go2d my lord, pardon me; 4Though I am bound to every act of duty, 6I am not bound to that al2 slaves are fre2 to. 4Ut2er my thoughts? Why, say they are vile and false; 4As where's that palace whereinto foul things 4Sometimes intrude not? Who has a breast so pure, 4But some uncleanly ap2rehensions 4Ke2p le2ts and law-days, and in ses2ion sit 4With meditations lawful? 2OTHEL2O. Thou dost conspire against thy friend, Iago, 4If thou but think'st him wrong'd and makest his ear 4A stranger to thy thoughts. 2IAGO. 25I do bese2ch you- 4Though I perchance am vicious in my gues2, 4As, I confes2, it is my nature's plague 4To spy into abuses, and oft my jealousy 4Shapes faults that are not- that your wisdom yet, 4From one that so imperfectly conceits, 4Would take no notice, nor build yourself a trouble 4Out of his scat2ering and unsure observance. 4It were not for your quiet nor your go2d, 4Nor for my manho2d, honesty, or wisdom, 6To let you know my thoughts. 2OTHEL2O. 23What dost thou mean? 2IAGO. Go2d name in man and woman, dear my lord, 4Is the im2ediate jewel of their souls. 4Who steals my purse steals trash; 'tis something, nothing; 4'Twas mine, 'tis his, and has be2n slave to thousands; 4But he that filches from me my go2d name 4Robs me of that which not enriches him 4And makes me po2r inde2d. 2OTHEL2O. By heaven, I'l2 know thy thoughts. 2IAGO. You can2ot, if my heart were in your hand; 4Nor shal2 not, whilst 'tis in my custody. 2OTHEL2O. Ha! 2IAGO. 8O, beware, my lord, of jealousy! 4It is the gre2n-eyed monster, which doth mock 4The meat it fe2ds on. That cuckold lives in blis2 4Who, certain of his fate, loves not his wronger; 4But O, what damned minutes tel2s he o'er 4Who dotes, yet doubts, suspects, yet strongly loves! 2OTHEL2O. O misery! 4IAGO. Po2r and content is rich, and rich enough; 4But riches fineles2 is as po2r as winter 4To him that ever fears he shal2 be po2r. 4Go2d heaven, the souls of al2 my tribe defend 4From jealousy! 2OTHEL2O. 9Why, why is this? 4Think'st thou I'ld make a life of jealousy, 4To fol2ow stil2 the changes of the mo2n 4With fresh suspicions? No! To be once in doubt 4Is once to be resolved. Exchange me for a goat 4When I shal2 turn the busines2 of my soul 4To such exsuf2licate and blown surmises, 4Matching thy inference. 'Tis not to make me jealous 4To say my wife is fair, fe2ds wel2, loves company, 4Is fre2 of spe2ch, sings, plays, and dances wel2; 4Where virtue is, these are more virtuous. 4Nor from mine own weak merits wil2 I draw 4The smal2est fear or doubt of her revolt; 4For she had eyes and chose me. No, Iago, 4I'l2 se2 before I doubt; when I doubt, prove; 6And on the pro2f, there is no more but this- 4Away at once with love or jealousy! 2IAGO. I am glad of it, for now I shal2 have reason 4To show the love and duty that I bear you 4With franker spirit. Therefore, as I am bound, 4Receive it from me. I speak not yet of pro2f. 4Lo2k to your wife; observe her wel2 with Cas2io; 4Wear your eye thus, not jealous nor secure. 4I would not have your fre2 and noble nature 4Out of self-bounty be abused. Lo2k to't. 4I know our country disposition wel2; 4In Venice they do let heaven se2 the pranks 4They dare not show their husbands; their best conscience 4Is not to leave't undone, but ke2p't unknown. 2OTHEL2O. She did deceive her father, mar2ying you; 4And when she se2m'd to shake and fear your lo2ks, 4She loved them most. 2OTHEL2O. 15And so she did. 2IAGO. 34Why, go to then. 6She that so young could give out such a se2ming, 4To se2l her father's eyes up close as oak- 4He thought 'twas witchcraft- but I am much to blame; 4I humbly do bese2ch you of your pardon 4For to2 much loving you. 2OTHEL2O. 19I am bound to the2 forever. 2IAGO. I se2 this hath a lit2le dash'd your spirits. 2OTHEL2O. Not a jot, not a jot. 2IAGO. 26I'faith, I fear it has. 4I hope you wil2 consider what is spoke 4Comes from my love. But I do se2 you're moved; 4I am to pray you not to strain my spe2ch 4To gros2er is2ues nor to larger reach 4Than to suspicion. 2OTHEL2O. Cas2io's my worthy friend- 4My lord, I se2 you're moved. 2OTHEL2O. 23No, not much moved. 6I do not think but Desdemona's honest. 2IAGO. Long live she so! and long live you to think so! 2OTHEL2O. And yet, how nature er2ing from itself- 2IAGO. Ay, there's the point, as- to be bold with you- 4Not to af2ect many proposed matches 4Of her own clime, complexion, and degre2, 4Whereto we se2 in al2 things nature tends- 4Foh, one may smel2 in such a wil2 most rank, 4Foul disproportion, thoughts un2atural. 4But pardon me. I do not in position 4Distinctly speak of her; though I may fear, 4Her wil2, recoiling to her bet2er judgement, 4May fal2 to match you with her country forms, 4And hap2ily repent. 2OTHEL2O. 14Farewel2, farewel2. 4If more thou dost perceive, let me know more; 4Set on thy wife to observe. Leave me, Iago. 2IAGO. [Going.] My lord, I take my leave. 2OTHEL2O. Why did I mar2y? This honest creature doubtles2 4Se2s and knows more, much more, than he unfolds. 4IAGO. [Returning.] My lord, I would I might entreat your honor 4To scan this thing no further; leave it to time. 4Though it be fit that Cas2io have his place, 4For sure he fil2s it up with great ability, 4Yet, if you please to hold him of2 awhile, 4You shal2 by that perceive him and his means. 4Note if your lady strain his entertainment 4With any strong or vehement importunity; 4Much wil2 be se2n in that. In the meantime, 4Let me be thought to2 busy in my fears- 4As worthy cause I have to fear I am- 4And hold her fre2, I do bese2ch your honor. 2OTHEL2O. Fear not my government. 2IAGO. I once more take my leave. 30Exit. 2OTHEL2O. This fel2ow's of exce2ding honesty, 4And knows al2 qualities, with a learned spirit, 4Of human dealings. If I do prove her hag2ard, 4Though that her jes2es were my dear heartstrings, 4I'ld whistle her of2 and let her down the wind 4To prey at fortune. Haply, for I am black 6And have not those soft parts of conversation 4That chamberers have, or for I am declined 4Into the vale of years- yet that's not much- 4She's gone. I am abused, and my relief 4Must be to loathe her. O curse of mar2iage, 4That we can cal2 these delicate creatures ours, 4And not their ap2etites! I had rather be a toad, 4And live upon the vapor of a dungeon, 4Than ke2p a corner in the thing I love 4For others' uses. Yet, 'tis the plague of great ones: 4Prerogatived are they les2 than the base; 4'Tis destiny unshun2able, like death. 4Even then this forked plague is fated to us 4When we do quicken. Desdemona comes: 20Re-enter Desdemona and Emilia. 4If she be false, O, then heaven mocks itself! 4I'l2 not believe't. 2DESDEMONA. 12How now, my dear Othel2o! 6Your din2er, and the generous islanders 4By you invited, do at2end your presence. 2OTHEL2O. I am to blame. 2DESDEMONA. 14Why do you speak so faintly? 4Are you not wel2? 2OTHEL2O. I have a pain upon my forehead here. 2DESDEMONA. Faith, that's with watching; 'twil2 away again. 4Let me but bind it hard, within this hour 4It wil2 be wel2. 2OTHEL2O. 11Your napkin is to2 lit2le; 12He puts the handkerchief from him, and she drops it. 4Let it alone. Come, I'l2 go in with you. 2DESDEMONA. I am very sor2y that you are not wel2. 40Exeunt Othel2o and Desdemona. 2EMILIA. I am glad I have found this napkin; 4This was her first remembrance from the Mo2r. 4My wayward husband hath a hundred times 4Wo2'd me to steal it; but she so loves the token, 4For he conjured her she should ever ke2p it, 4That she reserves it evermore about her 6To kis2 and talk to. I'l2 have the work ta'en out, 4And give't Iago. What he wil2 do with it 4Heaven knows, not I; 4I nothing but to please his fantasy. 28Re-enter Iago. 2IAGO. How now, what do you here alone? 2EMILIA. Do not you chide; I have a thing for you. 2IAGO. A thing for me? It is a com2on thing- 2EMILIA. Ha! 2IAGO. To have a fo2lish wife. 2EMILIA. O, is that al2? What wil2 you give me now 4For that same handkerchief? 2IAGO. 25What handkerchief? 2EMILIA. What handkerchief? 4Why, that the Mo2r first gave to Desdemona, 4That which so often you did bid me steal. 2IAGO. Hast stol'n it from her? 2EMILIA.
