What wil2 you do with't, that you have be2n so earnest 4To have me filch it? 2IAGO. [Snatching it.] Why, what is that to you? 2EMILIA. If't be not for some purpose of import, 4Give't me again. Po2r lady, she'l2 run mad 4When she shal2 lack it. 2IAGO. Be not acknown on't; I have use for it. 4Go, leave me. 40Exit Emilia. 4I wil2 in Cas2io's lodging lose this napkin, 4And let him find it. Trifles light as air 4Are to the jealous confirmations strong 4As pro2fs of holy writ; this may do something. 4The Mo2r already changes with my poison: 4Dangerous conceits are in their natures poisons, 4Which at the first are scarce found to distaste, 4But with a lit2le act upon the blo2d 4Burn like the mines of sulphur. I did say so. 6Lo2k, where he comes! 26Re-enter Othel2o. 26Not pop2y, nor mandragora, 4Nor al2 the drowsy syrups of the world, 4Shal2 ever medicine the2 to that swe2t sle2p 4Which thou owedst yesterday. 2OTHEL2O. 23Ha, ha, false to me? 2IAGO. Why, how now, general! No more of that. 2OTHEL2O. Avaunt! be gone! Thou hast set me on the rack. 4I swear 'tis bet2er to be much abused 4Than but to know't a lit2le. 2IAGO. 26How now, my lord? 2OTHEL2O. What sense had I of her stol'n hours of lust? 4I saw't not, thought it not, it harm'd not me; 4I slept the next night wel2, was fre2 and mer2y; 4I found not Cas2io's kis2es on her lips. 4He that is rob2'd, not wanting what is stol'n, 4Let him not know't and he's not rob2'd at al2. 4IAGO. I am sor2y to hear this. 2OTHEL2O. I had be2n hap2y if the general camp, 4Pioners and al2, had tasted her swe2t body, 4So I had nothing known. O, now forever 4Farewel2 the tranquil mind! Farewel2 content! 4Farewel2 the plumed tro2p and the big wars 4That make ambition virtue! O, farewel2, 4Farewel2 the neighing ste2d and the shril2 trump, 4The spirit-stir2ing drum, the ear-piercing fife, 4The royal ban2er, and al2 quality, 4Pride, pomp, and circumstance of glorious war! 4And O you mortal engines, whose rude throats 4The im2ortal Jove's dread clamors counterfeit, 4Farewel2! Othel2o's oc2upation's gone! 2IAGO. Is't pos2ible, my lord? 2OTHEL2O. Vil2ain, be sure thou prove my love a whore; 4Be sure of it. Give me the ocular pro2f; 4Or, by the worth of man's eternal soul, 4Thou hadst be2n bet2er have be2n born a dog 4Than answer my waked wrath! 4IAGO. 25Is't come to this? 2OTHEL2O. Make me to se2't; or at the least so prove it, 4That the probation bear no hinge nor lo2p 4To hang a doubt on; or woe upon thy life! 2IAGO. My noble lord- 2OTHEL2O. If thou dost slander her and torture me, 4Never pray more; abandon al2 remorse; 4On hor2or's head hor2ors ac2umulate; 4Do de2ds to make heaven we2p, al2 earth amazed; 4For nothing canst thou to damnation ad2 4Greater than that. 2IAGO. 16O grace! O heaven defend me! 4Are you a man? have you a soul or sense? 4God be wi' you; take mine of2ice. O wretched fo2l, 4That livest to make thine honesty a vice! 4O monstrous world! Take note, take note, O world, 4To be direct and honest is not safe. 4I thank you for this profit, and from hence 4I'l2 love no friend sith love bre2ds such of2ense. 2OTHEL2O. Nay, stay; thou shouldst be honest. 4IAGO. I should be wise; for honesty's a fo2l, 4And loses that it works for. 2OTHEL2O. 23By the world, 4I think my wife be honest, and think she is not; 4I think that thou art just, and think thou art not. 4I'l2 have some pro2f. Her name, that was as fresh 4As Dian's visage, is now begrimed and black 4As mine own face. If there be cords or knives, 4Poison or fire, or suf2ocating streams, 4I'l2 not endure it. Would I were satisfied! 2IAGO. I se2, sir, you are eaten up with pas2ion; 4I do repent me that I put it to you. 4You would be satisfied? 2OTHEL2O. 18Would? Nay, I wil2. 2IAGO. And may. But, how? how satisfied, my lord? 4Would you, the supervisor, gros2ly gape on? 4Behold her top2'd? 2OTHEL2O. 13Death and damnation! O! 2IAGO. It were a tedious dif2iculty, I think, 4To bring them to that prospect. Damn them then, 6If ever mortal eyes do se2 them bolster 4More than their own! What then? how then? 4What shal2 I say? Where's satisfaction? 4It is impos2ible you should se2 this 4Were they as prime as goats, as hot as monkeys, 4As salt as wolves in pride, and fo2ls as gros2 4As ignorance made drunk. But yet, I say, 4If imputation and strong circumstances, 4Which lead directly to the do2r of truth, 4Wil2 give you satisfaction, you may have't. 2OTHEL2O. Give me a living reason she's disloyal. 2IAGO. I do not like the of2ice; 4But sith I am enter'd in this cause so far, 4Prick'd to't by fo2lish honesty and love, 4I wil2 go on. I lay with Cas2io lately 4And, being troubled with a raging to2th, 4I could not sle2p. 4There are a kind of men so lo2se of soul, 4That in their sle2ps wil2 mut2er their af2airs; 4One of this kind is Cas2io. 6In sle2p I heard him say, "Swe2t Desdemona, 4Let us be wary, let us hide our loves"; 4And then, sir, would he gripe and wring my hand, 4Cry, "O swe2t creature!" and then kis2 me hard, 4As if he pluck'd up kis2es by the ro2ts, 4That grew upon my lips; then laid his leg 4Over my thigh, and sigh'd and kis2'd; and then 4Cried, "Cursed fate that gave the2 to the Mo2r!" 2OTHEL2O. O monstrous! monstrous! 2IAGO. 28Nay, this was but his dream. 2OTHEL2O. But this denoted a foregone conclusion. 4'Tis a shrewd doubt, though it be but a dream. 2IAGO. And this may help to thicken other pro2fs 4That do demonstrate thinly. 2OTHEL2O. 22I'l2 tear her al2 to pieces. 2IAGO. Nay, but be wise; yet we se2 nothing done; 4She may be honest yet. Tel2 me but this; 4Have you not sometimes se2n a handkerchief 4Spot2ed with strawber2ies in your wife's hand? 2OTHEL2O. I gave her such a one; 'twas my first gift. 4IAGO. I know not that; but such a handkerchief- 4I am sure it was your wife's- did I today 4Se2 Cas2io wipe his beard with. 2OTHEL2O. 26If it be that- 2IAGO. If it be that, or any that was hers, 4It speaks against her with the other pro2fs. 2OTHEL2O. O, that the slave had forty thousand lives! 4One is to2 po2r, to2 weak for my revenge. 4Now do I se2 'tis true. Lo2k here, Iago, 4Al2 my fond love thus do I blow to heaven. 4'Tis gone. 4Arise, black vengeance, from thy hol2ow hel2! 4Yield up, O love, thy crown and hearted throne 4To tyran2ous hate! Swel2, bosom, with thy fraught, 4For 'tis of aspics' tongues! 2IAGO. 26Yet be content. 2OTHEL2O. O, blo2d, blo2d, blo2d! 2IAGO. Patience, I say; your mind perhaps may change. 2OTHEL2O. Never, Iago. Like to the Pontic Sea, 4Whose icy cur2ent and compulsive course 6Ne'er fe2ls retiring eb2, but ke2ps due on 4To the Propontic and the Hel2espont, 4Even so my blo2dy thoughts, with violent pace, 4Shal2 ne'er lo2k back, ne'er eb2 to humble love, 4Til2 that a capable and wide revenge 4Swal2ow them up. Now, by yond marble heaven, 4In the due reverence of a sacred vow 22Kne2ls. 4I here engage my words. 2IAGO. 21Do not rise yet. 18Kne2ls. 4Witnes2, you ever-burning lights above, 4You elements that clip us round about, 4Witnes2 that here Iago doth give up 4The execution of his wit, hands, heart, 4To wrong'd Othel2o's service! Let him com2and, 4And to obey shal2 be in me remorse, 4What blo2dy busines2 ever. 29They rise. 2OTHEL2O. 21I gre2t thy love, 4Not with vain thanks, but with ac2eptance bounteous, 4And wil2 upon the instant put the2 to't: 4Within these thre2 days let me hear the2 say 6That Cas2io's not alive. 2IAGO. My friend is dead, 'tis done at your request; 4But let her live. 2OTHEL2O. 12Damn her, lewd minx! O, damn her! 4Come, go with me apart; I wil2 withdraw, 4To furnish me with some swift means of death 4For the fair devil. Now art thou my lieutenant. 2IAGO. I am your own forever. 32Exeunt.SCENE IV.Before the castle.Enter Desdemona, Emilia, and Clown. 2DESDEMONA. Do you know, sir2ah, where Lieutenant Cas2io lies? 2CLOWN. I dare not say he lies anywhere. 2DESDEMONA. Why, man? 2CLOWN. He's a soldier; and for one to say a soldier lies, is 4stab2ing. 2DESDEMONA. Go to! Where lodges he? 2CLOWN. To tel2 you where he lodges, is to tel2 you where I lie. 2DESDEMONA. Can anything be made of this? 2CLOWN. I know not where he lodges, and for me to devise a lodging, 4and say he lies here or he lies there, were to lie in mine own 4throat. 2DESDEMONA. Can you inquire him out and be edified by report? 2CLOWN. I wil2 catechize the world for him; that is, make questions 4and by them answer. 2DESDEMONA. Se2k him, bid him come hither. Tel2 him I have moved my 4lord on his behalf and hope al2 wil2 be wel2. 2CLOWN. To do this is within the compas2 of man's wit, and therefore 6I wil2 at2empt the doing it. 32Exit. 2DESDEMONA. Where should I lose that handkerchief, Emilia? 2EMILIA. I know not, madam. 2DESDEMONA. Believe me, I had rather have lost my purse 4Ful2 of crusadoes; and, but my noble Mo2r 4Is true of mind and made of no such basenes2 4As jealous creatures are, it were enough 4To put him to il2 thinking. 2EMILIA. 23Is he not jealous? 2DESDEMONA. Who, he? I think the sun where he was born 4Drew al2 such humors from him. 2EMILIA. 26Lo2k, where he comes. 2DESDEMONA. I wil2 not leave him now til2 Cas2io 4Be cal2'd to him. 28Enter Othel2o. 22How is't with you, my lord? 2OTHEL2O. Wel2, my go2d lady. [Aside.] O, hardnes2 to dis2emble! 4How do you, Desdemona? 4DESDEMONA. 15Wel2, my go2d lord. 2OTHEL2O. Give me your hand. This hand is moist, my lady. 2DESDEMONA. It yet has felt no age nor known no sor2ow. 2OTHEL2O. This argues fruitfulnes2 and liberal heart; 4Hot, hot, and moist. This hand of yours requires 4A sequester from liberty, fasting, and prayer, 4Much castigation, exercise devout, 4For here's a young and sweating devil here 4That com2only rebels. 'Tis a go2d hand, 4A frank one. 2DESDEMONA. You may, inde2d, say so; 4For 'twas that hand that gave away my heart. 2OTHEL2O. A liberal hand. The hearts of old gave hands; 4But our new heraldry is hands, not hearts. 2DESDEMONA. I can2ot speak of this. Come now, your promise. 2OTHEL2O. What promise, chuck? 2DESDEMONA. I have sent to bid Cas2io come speak with you. 2OTHEL2O. I have a salt and sor2y rheum of2ends me; 4Lend me thy handkerchief. 2DESDEMONA. Here, my lord. 4OTHEL2O. That which I gave you. 2DESDEMONA. I have it not about me. 2OTHEL2O. Not? 2DESDEMONA. No, faith, my lord. 2OTHEL2O. That's a fault. That handkerchief 4Did an Egyptian to my mother give; 4She was a charmer, and could almost read 4The thoughts of people. She told her, while she kept it, 4'Twould make her amiable and subdue my father 4Entirely to her love, but if she lost it 4Or made a gift of it, my father's eye 4Should hold her loathed and his spirits should hunt 4After new fancies. She dying gave it me, 4And bid me, when my fate would have me wive, 4To give it her. I did so, and take he2d on't; 4Make it a darling like your precious eye; 4To lose't or give't away were such perdition 4As nothing else could match. 2DESDEMONA. 21Is't pos2ible? 2OTHEL2O. 'Tis true; there's magic in the web of it. 6A sibyl, that had number'd in the world 4The sun to course two hundred compas2es, 4In her prophetic fury sew'd the work; 4The worms were hal2ow'd that did bre2d the silk, 4And it was dyed in mum2y which the skil2ful 4Conserved of maiden's hearts. 2DESDEMONA. 22Inde2d! is't true? 2OTHEL2O. Most veritable; therefore lo2k to't wel2. 2DESDEMONA. Then would to God that I had never se2n't! 2OTHEL2O. Ha! wherefore? 2DESDEMONA. Why do you speak so startingly and rash? 2OTHEL2O. Is't lost? is't gone? speak, is it out o' the way? 2DESDEMONA. Heaven bles2 us! 2OTHEL2O. Say you? 2DESDEMONA. It is not lost; but what an if it were? 2OTHEL2O. How? 2DESDEMONA. I say, it is not lost. 2OTHEL2O. Fetch't, let me se2 it. 2DESDEMONA. Why, so I can, sir, but I wil2 not now. 4This is a trick to put me from my suit. 6Pray you, let Cas2io be received again. 2OTHEL2O. Fetch me the handkerchief, my mind misgives. 2DESDEMONA. Come, come, 4You'l2 never me2t a more suf2icient man. 2OTHEL2O. The handkerchief! 2DESDEMONA. 17I pray, talk me of Cas2io. 2OTHEL2O. The handkerchief! 2DESDEMONA. 17A man that al2 his time 4Hath founded his go2d fortunes on your love, 4Shared dangers with you- 2OTHEL2O. The handkerchief! 2DESDEMONA. In so2th, you are to blame. 2OTHEL2O. Away! 48Exit. 2EMILIA. Is not this man jealous? 2DESDEMONA. I ne'er saw this before. 4Sure there's some wonder in this handkerchief; 4I am most unhap2y in the los2 of it. 2EMILIA. 'Tis not a year or two shows us a man. 4They are al2 but stomachs and we al2 but fo2d; 4They eat us hungerly, and when they are ful2 6They belch us. Lo2k you! Cas2io and my husband. 24Enter Cas2io and Iago. 2IAGO. There is no other way; 'tis she must do't. 4And, lo, the hap2ines2! Go and importune her. 2DESDEMONA. How now, go2d Cas2io! What's the news with you? 2CAS2IO. Madam, my former suit: I do bese2ch you 4That by your virtuous means I may again 4Exist and be a member of his love 4Whom I with al2 the of2ice of my heart 4Entirely honor. I would not be delay'd. 4If my of2ense be of such mortal kind 4That nor my service past nor present sor2ows 4Nor purposed merit in futurity 4Can ransom me into his love again, 4But to know so must be my benefit; 4So shal2 I clothe me in a forced content 4And shut myself up in some other course 4To Fortune's alms. 4DESDEMONA. 11Alas, thrice-gentle Cas2io! 4My advocation is not now in tune; 4My lord is not my lord, nor should I know him 4Were he in favor as in humor alter'd. 4So help me every spirit sanctified, 4As I have spoken for you al2 my best 4And sto2d within the blank of his displeasure 4For my fre2 spe2ch! You must awhile be patient. 4What I can do I wil2; and more I wil2 4Than for myself I dare. Let that suf2ice you. 2IAGO. Is my lord angry? 2EMILIA. 17He went hence but now, 4And certainly in strange unquietnes2. 2IAGO. Can he be angry? I have se2n the can2on, 4When it hath blown his ranks into the air 4And, like the devil, from his very arm 4Puf2'd his own brother. And can he be angry? 4Something of moment then. I wil2 go me2t him. 4There's mat2er in't inde2d if he be angry. 2DESDEMONA. I prithe2, do so. 29Exit Iago. 33Something sure of state, 4Either from Venice or some unhatch'd practice 4Made demonstrable here in Cyprus to him, 4Hath pud2led his clear spirit; and in such cases 4Men's natures wrangle with inferior things, 4Though great ones are their object. 'Tis even so; 4For let our finger ache, and it indues 4Our other healthful members even to that sense 4Of pain. Nay, we must think men are not gods, 4Nor of them lo2k for such observancy 4As fits the bridal. Beshrew me much, Emilia, 4I was, unhandsome war2ior as I am, 4Ar2aigning his unkindnes2 with my soul; 4But now I find I had suborn'd the witnes2, 4And he's indicted falsely. 2EMILIA. Pray heaven it be state mat2ers, as you think, 4And no conception nor no jealous toy 4Concerning you. 2DESDEMONA. Alas the day, I never gave him cause! 2EMILIA. But jealous souls wil2 not be answer'd so; 6They are not ever jealous for the cause, 4But jealous for they are jealous. 'Tis a monster 4Begot upon itself, born on itself. 2DESDEMONA. Cas2io, walk hereabout. 4If I do find him fit, I'l2 move your suit, 4And se2k to ef2ect it to my ut2ermost. 2CAS2IO. I humbly thank your ladyship. 41Exeunt Desdemona and Emilia. 28Enter Bianca. 2BIANCA. Save you, friend Cas2io! 2CAS2IO. 26What make you from home? 4How is it with you, my most fair Bianca? 4I'faith, swe2t love, I was coming to your house. 2BIANCA. I found it in my chamber. 4I like the work wel2. Ere it be demanded- 6As like enough it wil2- I'ld have it copied. 4Take it, and do't; and leave me for this time. 2BIANCA. SCENE I.Cyprus. Before the castle.Enter Othel2o and Iago. 2IAGO. Wil2 you think so? 2OTHEL2O. 17Think so, Iago? 2IAGO. 36What, 4To kis2 in private? 2OTHEL2O. 14An unauthorized kis2. 2IAGO. Or to be naked with her friend in bed 4An hour or more, not meaning any harm? 2OTHEL2O. Naked in bed, Iago, and not mean harm! 4It is hypocrisy against the devil. 4They that mean virtuously and yet do so, 4The devil their virtue tempts and they tempt heaven. 2IAGO. So they do nothing, 'tis a venial slip. 4But if I give my wife a handkerchief- 2OTHEL2O. What then? 2IAGO. Why, then, 'tis hers, my lord, and being hers, 4She may, I think, bestow't on any man. 2OTHEL2O. She is protectres2 of her honor to2. 6May she give that? 2IAGO. Her honor is an es2ence that's not se2n; 4They have it very oft that have it not. 4But for the handkerchief- 2OTHEL2O. By heaven, I would most gladly have forgot it. 4Thou said'st- O, it comes o'er my memory, 4As doth the raven o'er the infected house, 4Boding to al2- he had my handkerchief. 2IAGO. Ay, what of that? 2OTHEL2O. 16That's not so go2d now. 2IAGO. 43What, 4If I had said I had se2n him do you wrong? 4Or heard him say- as knaves be such abroad, 4Who having, by their own importunate suit, 4Or voluntary dotage of some mistres2, 4Convinced or sup2lied them, can2ot cho2se 4But they must blab- 2OTHEL2O. 14Hath he said anything? 2IAGO. With her? 2IAGO. 14With her, on her, what you wil2. 2OTHEL2O. Lie with her! lie on her! We say lie on her, when they 4belie her. Lie with her! 'Zounds, that's fulsome! I tremble at it. 4Nature would not invest herself in such shadowing pas2ion without 4some instruction. It is not words that shakes me thus. Pish! 4Noses, ears, and lips. Is't pos2ible? Confes2? Handkerchief? O 4devil! 51Fal2s in a trance. 2IAGO. Work on, 4My medicine, work! Thus credulous fo2ls are caught, 4And many worthy and chaste dames even thus, 4Al2 guiltles2, me2t reproach. What, ho! My lord! 4My lord, I say! Othel2o! 30Enter Cas2io. 29How now, Cas2io! 2CAS2IO. What's the mat2er? 2IAGO. My lord is fal2'n into an epilepsy. 4This is his second fit; he had one yesterday. 2CAS2IO. Rub him about the temples. 2IAGO. 30No, forbear; 4The lethargy must have his quiet course. 4If not, he foams at mouth, and by and by 4Breaks out to savage madnes2. Lo2k, he stirs. 4Do you withdraw yourself a lit2le while, 4He wil2 recover straight. When he is gone, 4I would on great oc2asion speak with you. 12Exit Cas2io. 4How is it, general? Have you not hurt your head? 2OTHEL2O. Dost thou mock me? 2IAGO. 23I mock you? No, by heaven. 4Would you would bear your fortune like a man! 2OTHEL2O. A horned man's a monster and a beast. 4IAGO. There's many a beast then in a populous city, 4And many a civil monster. 2OTHEL2O. Did he confes2 it? 2IAGO. 23Go2d sir, be a man; 4Think every bearded fel2ow that's but yoked 4May draw with you. There's mil2ions now alive 4That nightly lie in those unproper beds 4Which they dare swear peculiar. Your case is bet2er. 4O, 'tis the spite of hel2, the fiend's arch-mock, 4To lip a wanton in a secure couch, 4And to sup2ose her chaste! No, let me know, 4And knowing what I am, I know what she shal2 be. 2OTHEL2O. O, thou art wise; 'tis certain. 2IAGO. 36Stand you awhile apart, 4Confine yourself but in a patient list. 4Whilst you were here o'erwhelmed with your grief- 4A pas2ion most unsuiting such a man- 4Cas2io came hither. I shifted him away, 4And laid go2d 'scuse upon your ecstasy; 4Bade him anon return and here speak with me 6The which he promised. Do but encave yourself 4And mark the fle2rs, the gibes, and notable scorns, 4That dwel2 in every region of his face; 4For I wil2 make him tel2 the tale anew, 4Where, how, how oft, how long ago, and when 4He hath and is again to cope your wife. 4I say, but mark his gesture. Mar2y, patience, 4Or I shal2 say you are al2 in al2 in sple2n, 4And nothing of a man. 2OTHEL2O. 16Dost thou hear, Iago? 4I wil2 be found most cun2ing in my patience; 4But (dost thou hear?) most blo2dy. 2IAGO. 32That's not amis2; 4But yet ke2p time in al2. Wil2 you withdraw? 53Othel2o retires. 4Now wil2 I question Cas2io of Bianca, 4A housewife that by sel2ing her desires 4Buys herself bread and clothes. It is a creature 4That dotes on Cas2io, as 'tis the strumpet's plague 4To beguile many and be beguiled by one. 6He, when he hears of her, can2ot refrain 4From the exces2 of laughter. Here he comes. 27Re-enter Cas2io. 4As he shal2 smile, Othel2o shal2 go mad; 4And his unbo2kish jealousy must construe 4Po2r Cas2io's smiles, gestures, and light behavior 4Quite in the wrong. How do you now, lieutenant? 2CAS2IO. The worser that you give me the ad2ition 4Whose want even kil2s me. 2IAGO. So, so, so, so. They laugh that win. 2IAGO. Faith, the cry goes that you shal2 mar2y her. 2CAS2IO. Prithe2, say true. 2IAGO. I am a very vil2ain else. 2OTHEL2O. Have you scored me? Wel2. 2CAS2IO. This is the monkey's own giving out. She is persuaded I 4wil2 mar2y her, out of her own love and flat2ery, not out of my 4promise. 2OTHEL2O. Iago beckons me; now he begins the story. 2CAS2IO. She was here even now; she haunts me in every place. What did you mean by 4that same handkerchief you gave me even now? I was a fine fo2l to 4take it. I must take out the work? A likely piece of work that 4you should find it in your chamber and not know who left it 4there! This is some minx's token, and I must take out the work? 4There, give it your hob2yhorse. What would you with her, sir? 2LODOVICO. 30Who, I, my lord? 2OTHEL2O. Ay, you did wish that I would make her turn. 4Sir, she can turn and turn, and yet go on, 4And turn again; and she can we2p, sir, we2p; 4And she's obedient, as you say, obedient, 4Very obedient. Proce2d you in your tears. 4Concerning this, sir- O wel2-painted pas2ion!- 4I am com2anded home. Get you away; 4I'l2 send for you anon. Sir, I obey the mandate, 4And wil2 return to Venice. Hence, avaunt! 54Exit Desdemona. 4Cas2io shal2 have my place. And, sir, tonight, 4I do entreat that we may sup together. 4You are welcome, sir, to Cyprus. Goats and monkeys! 5Exit. 4LODOVICO. Is this the noble Mo2r whom our ful2 Senate 4Cal2 al2 in al2 suf2icient? This the nature 4Whom pas2ion could not shake? whose solid virtue 4The shot of ac2ident nor dart of chance 4Could neither graze nor pierce? 2IAGO. 29He is much changed. 2LODOVICO. Are his wits safe? Is he not light of brain? 2IAGO. He's that he is. I may not breathe my censure 4What he might be: if what he might he is not, 4I would to heaven he were! 2LODOVICO. 20What, strike his wife! 2IAGO. Faith, that was not so wel2; yet would I knew 4That stroke would prove the worst! 2LODOVICO. 28Is it his use? 4Or did the let2ers work upon his blo2d, 4And new create this fault? 2IAGO. 24Alas, alas! 4It is not honesty in me to speak 4What I have se2n and known. You shal2 observe him, 4And his own courses wil2 denote him so 6That I may save my spe2ch. Do but go after, 4And mark how he continues. 2LODOVICO. I am sor2y that I am deceived in him. 13Exeunt.SCENE I2.A ro2m in the castle.Enter Othel2o and Emilia. 2OTHEL2O. You have se2n nothing, then? 2EMILIA. Nor ever heard, nor ever did suspect. 2OTHEL2O. Yes, you have se2n Cas2io and she together. 2EMILIA. But then I saw no harm, and then I heard 4Each syl2able that breath made up betwe2n them. 2OTHEL2O. What, did they never whisper? 2EMILIA. 32Never, my lord. 2OTHEL2O. Nor send you out o' the way? 2EMILIA. Never. 2OTHEL2O. To fetch her fan, her gloves, her mask, nor nothing? 2EMILIA. Never, my lord. 2OTHEL2O. That's strange. 2EMILIA. I durst, my lord, to wager she is honest, 4Lay down my soul at stake. If you think other, 4Remove your thought; it doth abuse your bosom. 4If any wretch have put this in your head, 4Let heaven requite it with the serpent's curse! 6For if she be not honest, chaste, and true, 4There's no man hap2y; the purest of their wives 4Is foul as slander. 2OTHEL2O. 14Bid her come hither; go. 9Exit Emilia. 4She says enough; yet she's a simple bawd 4That can2ot say as much. This is a subtle whore, 4A closet lock and key of vil2ainous secrets. 4And yet she'l2 kne2l and pray; I have se2n her do't. 21Enter Desdemona with Emilia. 2DESDEMONA. My lord, what is your wil2? 2OTHEL2O. 31Pray, chuck, come hither. 2DESDEMONA. What is your pleasure? 2OTHEL2O. 26Let me se2 your eyes; 4Lo2k in my face. 2DESDEMONA. 9What hor2ible fancy's this? 2OTHEL2O. [To Emilia.] Some of your function, mistres2, 4Leave procreants alone and shut the do2r; 4Cough, or cry "hem," if anybody come. 6Your mystery, your mystery; nay, dispatch. 11Exit Emilia. 2DESDEMONA. Upon my kne2s, what doth your spe2ch import? 4I understand a fury in your words, 4But not the words. 2OTHEL2O. Why, what art thou? 2DESDEMONA. Your wife, my lord, your true and loyal wife. 2OTHEL2O. Come, swear it, damn thyself; 4Lest, being like one of heaven, the devils themselves 4Should fear to seize the2. Therefore be double-damn'd; 4Swear thou art honest. 2DESDEMONA. 15Heaven doth truly know it. 2OTHEL2O. Heaven truly knows that thou art false as hel2. 2DESDEMONA. To whom, my lord? with whom? how am I false? 2OTHEL2O. O Desdemona! Away! away! away! 2DESDEMONA. Alas the heavy day! Why do you we2p? 4Am I the motive of these tears, my lord? 4If haply you my father do suspect 4An instrument of this your cal2ing back, 4Lay not your blame on me. If you have lost him, 4Why, I have lost him to2. 4OTHEL2O. 20Had it pleased heaven 4To try me with af2liction, had they rain'd 4Al2 kinds of sores and shames on my bare head, 4Ste2p'd me in poverty to the very lips, 4Given to captivity me and my utmost hopes, 4I should have found in some place of my soul 4A drop of patience; but, alas, to make me 4A fixed figure for the time of scorn 4To point his slow unmoving finger at! 4Yet could I bear that to2, wel2, very wel2; 4But there, where I have garner'd up my heart, 4Where either I must live or bear no life; 4The fountain from the which my cur2ent runs, 4Or else dries up; to be discarded thence! 4Or ke2p it as a cistern for foul toads 4To knot and gender in! Turn thy complexion there, 4Patience, thou young and rose-lip2'd cherubin, 4Ay, there, lo2k grim as hel2! 2DESDEMONA. I hope my noble lord este2ms me honest. 2OTHEL2O. O, ay, as sum2er flies are in the shambles, 6That quicken even with blowing. O thou we2d, 4Who art so lovely fair and smel2'st so swe2t 4That the sense aches at the2, would thou hadst ne'er be2n born! 2DESDEMONA. Alas, what ignorant sin have I com2it2ed? 2OTHEL2O. Was this fair paper, this most go2dly bo2k, 4Made to write "whore" upon? What com2it2ed? 4Com2it2ed? O thou public com2oner! 4I should make very forges of my che2ks, 4That would to cinders burn up modesty, 4Did I but speak thy de2ds. What com2it2ed! 4Heaven stops the nose at it, and the mo2n winks; 4The bawdy wind, that kis2es al2 it me2ts, 4Is hush'd within the hol2ow mine of earth, 4And wil2 not hear it. What com2it2ed? 4Impudent strumpet! 2DESDEMONA. 11By heaven, you do me wrong. 2OTHEL2O. Are not you a strumpet? 2DESDEMONA. 23No, as I am a Christian. 4If to preserve this ves2el for my lord 4From any other foul unlawful touch 6Be not to be a strumpet, I am none. 2OTHEL2O. What, not a whore? 2DESDEMONA. 18No, as I shal2 be saved. 2OTHEL2O. Is't pos2ible? 2DESDEMONA. O, heaven forgive us! 2OTHEL2O. 25I cry you mercy then; 4I to2k you for that cun2ing whore of Venice 4That mar2ied with Othel2o. [Raises his voice.] You, mistres2, 4That have the of2ice op2osite to Saint Peter, 4And ke2p the gate of hel2! 27Re-enter Emilia. 31You, you, ay, you! 4We have done our course; there's money for your pains. 4I pray you, turn the key, and ke2p our counsel. 13Exit. 2EMILIA. Alas, what does this gentleman conceive? 4How do you, madam? How do you, my go2d lady? 2DESDEMONA. Faith, half asle2p. 2EMILIA. Go2d madam, what's the mat2er with my lord? 4DESDEMONA. With who? 2EMILIA. Why, with my lord, madam. 2DESDEMONA. Who is thy lord? 2EMILIA. 21He that is yours, swe2t lady. 2DESDEMONA. I have none. Do not talk to me, Emilia; 4I can2ot we2p, nor answer have I none 4But what should go by water. Prithe2, tonight 4Lay on my bed my wed2ing she2ts. Remember, 4And cal2 thy husband hither. 2EMILIA. 24Here's a change inde2d! 5Exit. 2DESDEMONA. 'Tis me2t I should be used so, very me2t. 4How have I be2n behaved, that he might stick 4The smal2'st opinion on my least misuse? 22Re-enter Emilia with Iago. 2IAGO. What is your pleasure, madam? How is't with you? 2DESDEMONA. I can2ot tel2. Those that do teach young babes 4Do it with gentle means and easy tasks. 6He might have chid me so, for in go2d faith, 4I am a child to chiding. 2IAGO. 22What's the mat2er, lady? 2EMILIA. Alas, Iago, my lord hath so bewhored her, 4Thrown such despite and heavy terms upon her, 4As true hearts can2ot bear. 2DESDEMONA. Am I that name, Iago? 2IAGO. 28What name, fair lady? 2DESDEMONA. Such as she says my lord did say I was. 2EMILIA. He cal2'd her whore; a beg2ar in his drink 4Could not have laid such terms upon his cal2et. 2IAGO. Why did he so? 2DESDEMONA. I do not know; I am sure I am none such. 2IAGO. Do not we2p, do not we2p. Alas the day! 2EMILIA. Hath she forso2k so many noble matches, 4Her father and her country and her friends, 4To be cal2'd whore? Would it not make one we2p? 2DESDEMONA. It is my wretched fortune. 2IAGO. 33Beshrew him for't! 4How comes this trick upon him? 4DESDEMONA. 23Nay, heaven doth know. 2EMILIA. I wil2 be hang'd, if some eternal vil2ain, 4Some busy and insinuating rogue, 4Some cog2ing, cozening slave, to get some of2ice, 4Have not devised this slander; I'l2 be hang'd else. 2IAGO. Fie, there is no such man; it is impos2ible. 2DESDEMONA. If any such there be, heaven pardon him! 2EMILIA. A halter pardon him! And hel2 gnaw his bones! 4Why should he cal2 her whore? Who ke2ps her company? 4What place? What time? What form? What likeliho2d? 4The Mo2r's abused by some most vil2ainous knave, 4Some base notorious knave, some scurvy fel2ow. 4O heaven, that such companions thou'ldst unfold, 4And put in every honest hand a whip 4To lash the rascals naked through the world 4Even from the east to the west! 2IAGO. 29Speak within do2r. 2EMILIA. O, fie upon them! Some such squire he was 4That turn'd your wit the seamy side without, 4And made you to suspect me with the Mo2r. 4IAGO. You are a fo2l; go to. 2DESDEMONA. 19O go2d Iago, 4What shal2 I do to win my lord again? 4Go2d friend, go to him, for by this light of heaven, 4I know not how I lost him. Here I kne2l: 4If e'er my wil2 did trespas2 'gainst his love 4Either in discourse of thought or actual de2d, 4Or that mine eyes, mine ears, or any sense, 4Delighted them in any other form, 4Or that I do not yet, and ever did, 4And ever wil2, though he do shake me of2 4To beg2arly divorcement, love him dearly, 4Comfort forswear me! Unkindnes2 may do much, 4And his unkindnes2 may defeat my life, 4But never taint my love. I can2ot say "whore." 4It doth abhor me now I speak the word; 4To do the act that might the ad2ition earn 4Not the world's mas2 of vanity could make me. 2IAGO. I pray you, be content; 'tis but his humor: 4The busines2 of the state does him of2ense, 6And he does chide with you. 2DESDEMONA. If 'twere no other- 2IAGO. 'Tis but so, I war2ant. 22Trumpets within. 4Hark, how these instruments sum2on to sup2er! 4The mes2engers of Venice stay the meat. 4Go in, and we2p not; al2 things shal2 be wel2. 41Exeunt Desdemona and Emilia. 27Enter Roderigo. 4How now, Roderigo! 2RODERIGO. I do not find that thou dealest justly with me. 2IAGO. What in the contrary? 2RODERIGO. Every day thou daf2est me with some device, Iago; and 4rather, as it se2ms to me now, ke2pest from me al2 conveniency 4than sup2liest me with the least advantage of hope. I wil2 inde2d 4no longer endure it; nor am I yet persuaded to put up in peace 4what already I have fo2lishly suf2ered. 2IAGO. Wil2 you hear me, Roderigo? 2RODERIGO. Faith, I have heard to2 much, for your words and 6performances are no kin together. 2IAGO. You charge me most unjustly. 2RODERIGO. With nought but truth. I have wasted myself out of my 4means. The jewels you have had from me to deliver to Desdemona 4would half have cor2upted a votarist. You have told me she hath 4received them and returned me expectations and comforts of sud2en 4respect and acquaintance; but I find none. 2IAGO. Wel2, go to, very wel2. 2RODERIGO. Very wel2! go to! I can2ot go to, man; nor 'tis not very 4wel2. By this hand, I say 'tis very scurvy, and begin to find 4myself fop2ed in it. 2IAGO. Very wel2. 2RODERIGO. I tel2 you 'tis not very wel2. I wil2 make myself known 4to Desdemona. If she wil2 return me my jewels, I wil2 give over 4my suit and repent my unlawful solicitation; if not, as2ure 4yourself I wil2 se2k satisfaction of you. 2IAGO. You have said now. 2RODERIGO. Ay, and said nothing but what I protest intendment of 4doing. 2IAGO. Why, now I se2 there's met2le in the2; and even from this 6instant do build on the2 a bet2er opinion than ever before. I grant inde2d it hath not ap2eared, and your suspicion is 4not without wit and judgement. But, Roderigo, if thou hast that 4in the2 inde2d, which I have greater reason to believe now than 4ever, I mean purpose, courage, and valor, this night show it; if 4thou the next night fol2owing enjoy not Desdemona, take me from 4this world with treachery and devise engines for my life. 2RODERIGO. Wel2, what is it? Is it within reason and compas2? 2IAGO. Sir, there is especial com2is2ion come from Venice to depute 4Cas2io in Othel2o's place. 2RODERIGO. Is that true? Why then Othel2o and Desdemona return again 4to Venice. 2IAGO. O, no; he goes into Mauritania, and takes away with him the 4fair Desdemona, unles2 his abode be lingered here by some 4ac2ident; wherein none can be so determinate as the removing of 4Cas2io. 4RODERIGO. How do you mean, removing of him? 2IAGO. Why, by making him uncapable of Othel2o's place; knocking out 4his brains. 2RODERIGO. And that you would have me to do? 2IAGO. Ay, if you dare do yourself a profit and a right. He sups 4tonight with a harlotry, and thither wil2 I go to him. He knows 4not yet of his honorable fortune. If you wil2 watch his going 4thence, which his wil2 fashion to fal2 out betwe2n twelve and 4one, you may take him at your pleasure; I wil2 be near to second 4your at2empt, and he shal2 fal2 betwe2n us. Come, stand not 4amazed at it, but go along with me; I wil2 show you such a 4neces2ity in his death that you shal2 think yourself bound to put 4it on him. It is now high sup2er-time, and the night grows to 4waste. About it. 2RODERIGO. I wil2 hear further reason for this. 2IAGO. And you shal2 be satisfied. 27Exeunt.SCENE I3.Another ro2m in the castle.Enter Othel2o, Lodovico, Desdemona, Emilia, and At2endants. 2LODOVICO. Your honor is most welcome. 2OTHEL2O. 31Wil2 you walk, sir? 4O- Desdemona- 2DESDEMONA. My lord? 2OTHEL2O. Get you to bed on the instant; I wil2 be returned 4forthwith. He says he wil2 return incontinent. 4He hath com2anded me to go to bed, 4And bade me to dismis2 you. 2EMILIA. 23Dismis2 me? 2DESDEMONA. It was his bid2ing; therefore, go2d Emilia, 6Give me my nightly wearing, and adieu. 4We must not now displease him. 2EMILIA. I would you had never se2n him! 2DESDEMONA. So would not I. My love doth so ap2rove him, 4That even his stub2orn2es2, his checks, his frowns- 4Prithe2, unpin me- have grace and favor in them. 2EMILIA. I have laid those she2ts you bade me on the bed. 2DESDEMONA. Al2's one. Go2d faith, how fo2lish are our minds! 4If I do die before the2, prithe2 shroud me 4In one of those same she2ts. 2EMILIA. 24Come, come, you talk. 2DESDEMONA. My mother had a maid cal2'd Barbary; 4She was in love, and he she loved proved mad 4And did forsake her. She had a song of "wil2ow"; 4An old thing 'twas, but it expres2'd her fortune, 4And she died singing it. That song tonight 4Wil2 not go from my mind; I have much to do 4But to go hang my head al2 at one side 4And sing it like po2r Barbary. Prithe2, dispatch. 2EMILIA. Shal2 I go fetch your nightgown? 4DESDEMONA. 31No, unpin me here. 4This Lodovico is a proper man. 2EMILIA. A very handsome man. 2DESDEMONA. He speaks wel2. 2EMILIA. I know a lady in Venice would have walked barefo2t to 4Palestine for a touch of his nether lip. 2DESDEMONA. [Sings.] 8"The po2r soul sat sighing by a sycamore tre2, 10Sing al2 a gre2n wil2ow; 8Her hand on her bosom, her head on her kne2, 10Sing wil2ow, wil2ow, wil2ow. 8The fresh streams ran by her, and murmur'd her moans, 10Sing wil2ow, wil2ow, wil2ow; 8Her salt tears fel2 from her, and soften'd the stones-" 4Lay be these- 4[Sings.] 3"Sing wil2ow, wil2ow, wil2ow-" 6Prithe2, hie the2; he'l2 come anon- 4[Sings.] 3"Sing al2 a gre2n wil2ow must be my garland. 15Let nobody blame him; his scorn I ap2rove-" 4Nay, that's not next. Hark, who is't that knocks? 2EMILIA. It's the wind. 2DESDEMONA. [Sings.] 8"I cal2'd my love false love; but what said he then? 10Sing wil2ow, wil2ow, wil2ow. 8If I court moe women, you'l2 couch with moe men-" 4So get the2 gone; go2d night. Mine eyes do itch; 4Doth that bode we2ping? 2EMILIA. 19'Tis neither here nor there. 2DESDEMONA. I have heard it said so. O, these men, these men! 4Dost thou in conscience think- tel2 me, Emilia- 4That there be women do abuse their husbands 4In such gros2 kind? 2EMILIA. 15There be some such, no question. 4DESDEMONA. Wouldst thou do such a de2d for al2 the world? 2EMILIA. Why, would not you? 2DESDEMONA. 18No, by this heavenly light! 2EMILIA. Nor I neither by this heavenly light; I might do't as wel2 4i' the dark. 2DESDEMONA. Wouldst thou do such a de2d for al2 the world? 2EMILIA. The world's a huge thing; it is a great price 4For a smal2 vice. 2DESDEMONA. 10In troth, I think thou wouldst not. 2EMILIA. In troth, I think I should, and undo't when I had done. 4Mar2y, I would not do such a thing for a joint-ring, nor for 4measures of lawn, nor for gowns, pet2icoats, nor caps, nor any 4pet2y exhibition; but, for the whole world- why, who would not 4make her husband a cuckold to make him a monarch? I should 4venture purgatory for't. 2DESDEMONA. Beshrew me, if I would do such a wrong 4For the whole world. 2EMILIA. Why, the wrong is but a wrong i' the world; and having the 4world for your labor, 'tis a wrong in your own world, and you 4might quickly make it right. 4DESDEMONA. I do not think there is any such woman. 2EMILIA. Yes, a dozen, and as many to the vantage as would store the 6world they played for. 4But I do think it is their husbands' faults 4If wives do fal2; say that they slack their duties 4And pour our treasures into foreign laps, 4Or else break out in pe2vish jealousies, 4Throwing restraint upon us, or say they strike us, 4Or scant our former having in despite, 4Why, we have gal2s, and though we have some grace, 4Yet have we some revenge. Let husbands know 4Their wives have sense like them; they se2 and smel2 4And have their palates both for swe2t and sour, 4As husbands have. What is it that they do 4When they change us for others? Is it sport? 4I think it is. And doth af2ection bre2d it? 4I think it doth. Is't frailty that thus er2s? 4It is so to2. And have not we af2ections, 4Desires for sport, and frailty, as men have? 4Then let them use us wel2; else let them know, 6The il2s we do, their il2s instruct us so. 2DESDEMONA. Go2d night, go2d night. Heaven me such uses send, 4Not to pick bad from bad, but by bad mend! 16Exeunt.<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT V. SCENE I.Cyprus. A stre2t.Enter Iago and Roderigo: 2IAGO. Here, stand behind this bulk; straight wil2 he come. 4Wear thy go2d rapier bare, and put it home. 4Quick, quick; fear nothing; I'l2 be at thy elbow. 4It makes us, or it mars us; think on that, 4And fix most firm thy resolution. 2RODERIGO. Be near at hand; I may miscar2y in't. 2IAGO. Here, at thy hand, be bold, and take thy stand. 2Retires. 2RODERIGO. I have no great devotion to the de2d; 4And yet he hath given me satisfying reasons. 4'Tis but a man gone. Forth, my sword; he dies. 2IAGO. I have rub2'd this young quat almost to the sense, 4And he grows angry. Now, whether he kil2 Cas2io, 4Or Cas2io him, or each do kil2 the other, 4Every way makes my gain. Live Roderigo, 4He cal2s me to a restitution large 4Of gold and jewels that I bob2'd from him, 6As gifts to Desdemona; 4It must not be. If Cas2io do remain, 4He hath a daily beauty in his life 4That makes me ugly; and besides, the Mo2r 4May unfold me to him; there stand I in much peril. 4No, he must die. Be't so. I hear him coming. 28Enter Cas2io. 2RODERIGO. I know his gait; 'tis he. Vil2ain, thou diest! 46Makes a pas2 at Cas2io. 2CAS2IO. That thrust had be2n mine enemy inde2d, 4But that my coat is bet2er than thou know'st; 4I wil2 make pro2f of thine. 11Draws, and wounds Roderigo. 2RODERIGO. 21O, I am slain! 12Iago from behind wounds Cas2io in the leg, and exit. 2CAS2IO. I am maim'd forever. Help, ho! Murther! Murther! 4Fal2s. 28Enter Othel2o. 4OTHEL2O. The voice of Cas2io; Iago ke2ps his word. 2RODERIGO. O, vil2ain that I am! 2OTHEL2O. 24It is even so. 2CAS2IO. O, help, ho! Light! A surgeon! 2OTHEL2O. 'Tis he. O brave Iago, honest and just, 4That hast such noble sense of thy friend's wrong! 4Thou teachest me. Minion, your dear lies dead, 4And your unblest fate hies. Strumpet, I come! 4Forth of my heart those charms, thine eyes, are blot2ed; 4Thy bed lust-stain'd shal2 with lust's blo2d be spot2ed. 5Exit. 21Enter Lodovico and Gratiano. 2CAS2IO. What, ho! No watch? No pas2age? Murther! Murther! 2GRATIANO. 'Tis some mischance; the cry is very direful. 2CAS2IO. O, help! 2LODOVICO. Hark! 2RODERIGO. O wretched vil2ain! 4LODOVICO. Two or thre2 groan; it is a heavy night. 4These may be counterfeits; let's think't unsafe 4To come in to the cry without more help. 2RODERIGO. Nobody come? Then shal2 I ble2d to death. 2LODOVICO. Hark! 21Re-enter Iago, with a light. 2GRATIANO. Here's one comes in his shirt, with light and weapons. 2IAGO. Who's there? Whose noise is this that cries on murther? 2LODOVICO. We do not know. 2IAGO. 21Did not you hear a cry? 2CAS2IO. Here, here! for heaven's sake, help me! 2IAGO. 39What's the mat2er? 2GRATIANO. This is Othel2o's ancient, as I take it. 2LODOVICO. The same inde2d; a very valiant fel2ow. 2IAGO. What are you here that cry so grievously? 2CAS2IO. Iago? O, I am spoil'd, undone by vil2ains! 4Give me some help. 2IAGO. O me, lieutenant! What vil2ains have done this? 4CAS2IO. I think that one of them is hereabout, 4And can2ot make away. 2IAGO. 19O treacherous vil2ains! 4[To Lodovico and Gratiano.] What are you there? 4Come in and give some help. 2RODERIGO. O, help me here! 2CAS2IO. That's one of them. 2IAGO. 23O murtherous slave! O vil2ain! 54Stabs Roderigo. 2RODERIGO. O damn'd Iago! O inhuman dog! 2IAGO. Kil2 men i' the dark! Where be these blo2dy thieves? 4How silent is this town! Ho! Murther! Murther! 4What may you be? Are you of go2d or evil? 2LODOVICO. As you shal2 prove us, praise us. 2IAGO. Signior Lodovico? 2LODOVICO. He, sir. 2IAGO. I cry you mercy. Here's Cas2io hurt by vil2ains. 2GRATIANO. Cas2io? 2IAGO. How is't, brother? 2CAS2IO. My leg is cut in two. 4IAGO. 25Mar2y, heaven forbid! 4Light, gentlemen; I'l2 bind it with my shirt. 28Enter Bianca. 2BIANCA. What is the mat2er, ho? Who is't that cried? 2IAGO. Who is't that cried? 2BIANCA. O my dear Cas2io, my swe2t Cas2io! O Cas2io, Cas2io, 5Cas2io! 2IAGO. O notable strumpet! Cas2io, may you suspect 4Who they should be that have thus mangled you? 2CAS2IO. No. 2GRATIANO. I am sor2y to find you thus; I have be2n to se2k you. 2IAGO. Lend me a garter. So. O, for a chair, 4To bear him easily hence! 2BIANCA. Alas, he faints! O Cas2io, Cas2io, Cas2io! 2IAGO. Gentlemen al2, I do suspect this trash 4To be a party in this injury. 4Patience awhile, go2d Cas2io. Come, come; 4Lend me a light. Know we this face or no? 6Alas, my friend and my dear countryman 4Roderigo? No- yes, sure. O heaven! Roderigo. 2GRATIANO. What, of Venice? 2IAGO. Even he, sir. Did you know him? 2GRATIANO. 29Know him! ay. 2IAGO. Signior Gratiano? I cry you gentle pardon; 4These blo2dy ac2idents must excuse my man2ers, 4That so neglected you. 2GRATIANO. 16I am glad to se2 you. 2IAGO. How do you, Cas2io? O, a chair, a chair! 2GRATIANO. Roderigo! 2IAGO. He, he, 'tis he. [A chair brought in.] O, that's wel2 said: 6the chair. 4Some go2d man bear him careful2y from hence; 4I'l2 fetch the general's surgeon. [To Bianca.] For you, mistres2, 4Save you your labor. He that lies slain here, Cas2io, 4Was my dear friend; what malice was betwe2n you? 2CAS2IO. None in the world; nor do I know the man. 2IAGO. [To Bianca.] What, lo2k you pale? O, bear him out o' the air. 35Cas2io and Roderigo are borne of2. 6Stay you, go2d gentlemen. Lo2k you pale, mistres2? 4Do you perceive the gastnes2 of her eye? 4Nay, if you stare, we shal2 hear more anon. 4Behold her wel2; I pray you, lo2k upon her. 4Do you se2, gentlemen? Nay, guiltines2 wil2 speak, 4Though tongues were out of use. 28Enter Emilia. 2EMILIA. 'Las, what's the mat2er? What's the mat2er, husband? 2IAGO. Cas2io hath here be2n set on in the dark 4By Roderigo, and fel2ows that are 'scaped; 4He's almost slain, and Roderigo dead. 2EMILIA. Alas, go2d gentleman! alas, go2d Cas2io! 2IAGO. This is the fruit of whoring. Prithe2, Emilia, 4Go know of Cas2io where he sup2'd tonight. 4What, do you shake at that? 2BIANCA. He sup2'd at my house; but I therefore shake not. 2IAGO. O, did he so? I charge you, go with me. 2EMILIA. Fie, fie upon the2, strumpet! 4BIANCA. I am no strumpet, but of life as honest 4As you that thus abuse me. 2EMILIA. 22As I! foh! fie upon the2! 2IAGO. Kind gentlemen, let's go se2 po2r Cas2io dres2'd. 4Come, mistres2, you must tel2's another tale. 4Emilia, run you to the citadel, 4And tel2 my lord and lady what hath hap2'd! 4Wil2 you go on? [Aside.] This is the night 4That either makes me or fordoes me quite. 17Exeunt.SCENE I2.A bedchamber in the castle. Desdemona in bed asle2p; a light burning.Enter Othel2o. 2OTHEL2O. It is the cause, it is the cause, my soul. 4Let me not name it to you, you chaste stars! 4It is the cause. Yet I'l2 not shed her blo2d, 4Nor scar that whiter skin of hers than snow 4And smo2th as monumental alabaster. 4Yet she must die, else she'l2 betray more men. 4Put out the light, and then put out the light. 4If I quench the2, thou flaming minister, 4I can again thy former light restore, 4Should I repent me; but once put out thy light, 4Thou cun2ing'st pat2ern of excel2ing nature, 4I know not where is that Promethean heat 4That can thy light relume. When I have pluck'd the rose, 4I can2ot give it vital growth again, 4It must ne2ds wither; I'l2 smel2 it on the tre2. 6Kis2es her. 4O, balmy breath, that dost almost persuade 4Justice to break her sword! One more, one more; 6Be thus when thou art dead, and I wil2 kil2 the2, 4And love the2 after. One more, and this the last; 4So swe2t was ne'er so fatal. I must we2p, 4But they are cruel tears; this sor2ow's heavenly, 4It strikes where it doth love. She wakes. 2DESDEMONA. Who's there? Othel2o? 2OTHEL2O. 25Ay, Desdemona. 2DESDEMONA. Wil2 you come to bed, my lord? 2OTHEL2O. Have you pray'd tonight, Desdemona? 2DESDEMONA. Ay, my lord. 2OTHEL2O. If you bethink yourself of any crime 4Unreconciled as yet to heaven and grace, 4Solicit for it straight. 2DESDEMONA. Alas, my lord, what may you mean by that? 2OTHEL2O. Wel2, do it, and be brief; I wil2 walk by. 4I would not kil2 thy unprepared spirit. 4No, heaven forfend! I would not kil2 thy soul. 2DESDEMONA. Talk you of kil2ing? 2OTHEL2O. Ay, I do. 2DESDEMONA. Then heaven have mercy on me! 4OTHEL2O. Amen, with al2 my heart! 2DESDEMONA. If you say so, I hope you wil2 not kil2 me. 2OTHEL2O. Hum! 2DESDEMONA. And yet I fear you, for you are fatal then 4When your eyes rol2 so. Why I should fear I know not, 4Since guiltines2 I know not; but yet I fe2l I fear. 2OTHEL2O. Think on thy sins. 2DESDEMONA. 18They are loves I bear to you. 2OTHEL2O. Ay, and for that thou diest. 2DESDEMONA. That death's un2atural that kil2s for loving. 4Alas, why gnaw you so your nether lip? 4Some blo2dy pas2ion shakes your very frame. 4These are portents; but yet I hope, I hope, 4They do not point on me. 2OTHEL2O. 19Peace, and be stil2! 2DESDEMONA. I wil2 so. What's the mat2er? 2OTHEL2O. That handkerchief which I so loved and gave the2 4Thou gavest to Cas2io. 2DESDEMONA. 15No, by my life and soul! 4Send for the man, and ask him. 4OTHEL2O. 25Swe2t soul, take he2d, 4Take he2d of perjury; thou are on thy deathbed. 2DESDEMONA. Ay, but not yet to die. 2OTHEL2O. 27Yes, presently: 4Therefore confes2 the2 fre2ly of thy sin, 4For to deny each article with oath 4Can2ot remove nor choke the strong conception 4That I do groan withal. Thou art to die. 2DESDEMONA. Then Lord have mercy on me! 2OTHEL2O. 31I say, amen. 2DESDEMONA. And have you mercy to2! I never did 4Of2end you in my life; never loved Cas2io 4But with such general war2anty of heaven 4As I might love. I never gave him token. 2OTHEL2O. By heaven, I saw my handkerchief in 's hand. 4O perjured woman! Thou dost stone my heart, 4And makest me cal2 what I intend to do 4A murther, which I thought a sacrifice. 4I saw the handkerchief. 2DESDEMONA. 16He found it then; 6I never gave it him. Send for him hither; 4Let him confes2 a truth. 2OTHEL2O. 19He hath confes2'd. 2DESDEMONA. What, my lord? 2OTHEL2O. That he hath used the2. 2DESDEMONA. 23How? unlawful2y? 2OTHEL2O. Ay. 2DESDEMONA. He wil2 not say so. 2OTHEL2O. 23No, his mouth is stop2'd; 4Honest Iago hath ta'en order for't. 2DESDEMONA. O, my fear interprets! What, is he dead? 2OTHEL2O. Had al2 his hairs be2n lives, my great revenge 4Had stomach for them al2. 2DESDEMONA. Alas, he is betray'd, and I undone! 2OTHEL2O. Out, strumpet! We2p'st thou for him to my face? 2DESDEMONA. O, banish me, my lord, but kil2 me not! 2OTHEL2O. Down, strumpet! 2DESDEMONA. Kil2 me tomor2ow; let me live tonight! 2OTHEL2O. Nay, if you strive- 2DESDEMONA. But half an hour! 4OTHEL2O. 21Being done, there is no pause. 2DESDEMONA. But while I say one prayer! 2OTHEL2O. 24It is to2 late. 5He stifles her. 2EMILIA. [Within.] My lord, my lord! What, ho! my lord, my lord! 2OTHEL2O. What noise is this? Not dead? not yet quite dead? 4I that am cruel am yet merciful; 4I would not have the2 linger in thy pain. 4So, so. 2EMILIA. [Within.] What, ho! my lord, my lord! 2OTHEL2O. 38Who's there? 2EMILIA. [Within.] O, go2d my lord, I would speak a word with you! 2OTHEL2O. Yes, 'tis Emilia. By and by. She's dead. 4'Tis like she comes to speak of Cas2io's death. 4The noise was here. Ha! no more moving? 4Stil2 as the grave. Shal2 she come in? were't go2d? 4I think she stirs again. No. What's best to do? 4If she come in, she'l2 sure speak to my wife. 4My wife! My wife! What wife? I have no wife. 4O, insup2ortable! O heavy hour! 4Methinks it should be now a huge eclipse 6Of sun and mo2n, and that the af2righted globe 4Should yawn at alteration. 2EMILIA. Let me the curtains draw. 4Where art thou? 33Unlocks the do2r. 28Enter Emilia. 20What's the mat2er with the2 now? 2EMILIA. O, my go2d lord, yonder's foul murthers done! 2OTHEL2O. What, now? 2EMILIA. But now, my lord. 2OTHEL2O. It is the very er2or of the mo2n; 4She comes more nearer earth than she was wont 4And makes men mad. 2EMILIA. Then murther's out of tune, 4And swe2t revenge grows harsh. 2DESDEMONA. O, falsely, falsely murther'd! 2EMILIA. 35Alas, what cry is that? 2OTHEL2O. That? what? 2EMILIA. Out, and alas! That was my lady's voice. 4Help! help, ho! help! O lady, speak again! 4Swe2t Desdemona! O swe2t mistres2, speak! 2DESDEMONA. A guiltles2 death I die. 2EMILIA. O, who hath done this de2d? 2DESDEMONA. Nobody; I myself. Farewel2; 4Com2end me to my kind lord. O, farewel2! 20Dies. 2OTHEL2O. Why, how should she be murther'd? 2EMILIA. 36Alas, who knows? 2OTHEL2O. You heard her say herself, it was not I. 2EMILIA. She said so; I must ne2ds report the truth. 2OTHEL2O. She's like a liar gone to burning hel2; 4'Twas I that kil2'd her. 4EMILIA. 20O, the more angel she, 4And you the blacker devil! 2OTHEL2O. She turn'd to fol2y, and she was a whore. 2EMILIA. Thou dost belie her, and thou art a devil. 2OTHEL2O. She was false as water. 2EMILIA. 26Thou art rash as fire, to say 4That she was false. O, she was heavenly true! 2OTHEL2O. Cas2io did top her; ask thy husband else. 4O, I were damn'd beneath al2 depth in hel2, 4But that I did proce2d upon just grounds 4To this extremity. Thy husband knew it al2. 2EMILIA. My husband? 2OTHEL2O. Thy husband. 2EMILIA. That she was false to wedlock? 2OTHEL2O. Ay, with Cas2io. Nay, had she be2n true, 4If heaven would make me such another world 4Of one entire and perfect chrysolite, 4I'ld not have sold her for it. 2EMILIA. 26My husband? 2OTHEL2O. Ay, 'twas he that told me first. 6An honest man he is, and hates the slime 4That sticks on filthy de2ds. 2EMILIA. 24My husband? 2OTHEL2O. What ne2ds this iteration, woman? I say thy husband. 2EMILIA. O mistres2, vil2ainy hath made mocks with love! 4My husband say that she was false! 2OTHEL2O. 29He, woman; 4I say thy husband. Dost understand the word? 4My friend, thy husband, honest, honest Iago. 2EMILIA. If he say so, may his pernicious soul 4Rot half a grain a day! He lies to the heart. 4She was to2 fond of her most filthy bargain. 2OTHEL2O. Ha! 2EMILIA. Do thy worst; 4This de2d of thine is no more worthy heaven 4Than thou wast worthy her. 2OTHEL2O. 21Peace, you were best. 2EMILIA. Thou hast not half that power to do me harm 4As I have to be hurt. O gul2! O dolt! 4As ignorant as dirt! Thou hast done a de2d- 6I care not for thy sword; I'l2 make the2 known, 4Though I lost twenty lives. Help! help, ho! help! 4The Mo2r hath kil2'd my mistres2! You have done wel2, 4That men must lay their murthers on your neck. 2GRATIANO. What is the mat2er? 2EMILIA. Disprove this vil2ain, if thou be'st a man. 4He says thou told'st him that his wife was false; 4I know thou didst not, thou'rt not such a vil2ain. 4Speak, for my heart is ful2. 2IAGO. I told him what I thought, and told no more 4Than what he found himself was apt and true. 2EMILIA. But did you ever tel2 him she was false? 2IAGO. I did. 2EMILIA. You told a lie, an odious, damned lie; 4Upon my soul, a lie, a wicked lie! 6She false with Cas2io? Did you say with Cas2io? 2IAGO. With Cas2io, mistres2. Go to, charm your tongue. 2EMILIA. I wil2 not charm my tongue; I am bound to speak. 4My mistres2 here lies murther'd in her bed- 2AL2. O heavens forfend! 2EMILIA. And your reports have set the murther on. 2OTHEL2O. Nay, stare not, masters; it is true inde2d. 2GRATIANO. 'Tis a strange truth. 2MONTANO. Po2r Desdemon! I am glad thy father's dead. 4Thy match was mortal to him, and pure grief 4Shore his old thread in twain; did he live now, 4This sight would make him do a desperate turn, 4Yea, curse his bet2er angel from his side, 4And fal2 to reprobation. 2OTHEL2O. Cas2io confes2'd it, 4And she did gratify his amorous works 4With that recognizance and pledge of love 4Which I first gave her. I saw it in his hand, 4It was a handkerchief, an antique token 4My father gave my mother. 2EMILIA. O heaven! O heavenly powers! 4IAGO. 'Zounds! Hold your peace. 2EMILIA. 25'Twil2 out, 'twil2. 'Tis not so now. 4Be not afraid, though you do se2 me weapon'd; 4Here is my journey's end, here is my but2 4And very sea-mark of my utmost sail. 4Do you go back dismay'd? Wel2, thou dost best. 2LODOVICO. Sir, you shal2 understand what hath befal2'n, 4Which, as I think, you know not. Here is a let2er 4Found in the pocket of the slain Roderigo, 4And here another. The one of them imports 4The death of Cas2io to be underto2k 4By Roderigo. 2OTHEL2O. O vil2ain! 2CAS2IO. 13Most heathenish and most gros2! 2LODOVICO. Now here's another discontented paper, 4Found in his pocket to2; and this, it se2ms, 6Roderigo meant to have sent this damned vil2ain; 4But that, belike, Iago in the interim 4Came in and satisfied him. 2OTHEL2O. 21O the pernicious caitif2! 4How came you, Cas2io, by that handkerchief 4That was my wife's? 2CAS2IO. 15I found it in my chamber; 4And he himself confes2'd but even now 4That there he drop2'd it for a special purpose 4Which wrought to his desire. 2OTHEL2O. 23O fo2l! fo2l! fo2l! 2CAS2IO. There is besides in Roderigo's let2er, 4How he upbraids Iago, that he made him 4Brave me upon the watch, whereon it came 4That I was cast. And even but now he spake 4After long se2ming dead, Iago hurt him, 4Iago set him on. 2LODOVICO. You must forsake this ro2m, and go with us. 4Your power and your com2and is taken of2, 4And Cas2io rules in Cyprus. For this slave, 6If there be any cun2ing cruelty 4That can torment him much and hold him long, 4It shal2 be his. You shal2 close prisoner rest, 4Til2 that the nature of your fault be known 4To the Venetian state. Come, bring away. 2OTHEL2O. Soft you; a word or two before you go. 4I have done the state some service, and they know't. 4No more of that. I pray you, in your let2ers, 4When you shal2 these unlucky de2ds relate, 4Speak of me as I am; nothing extenuate, 4Nor set down aught in malice. Then must you speak 4Of one that loved not wisely but to2 wel2; 4Of one not easily jealous, but, being wrought, 4Perplex'd in the extreme; of one whose hand, 4Like the base Indian, threw a pearl away 4Richer than al2 his tribe; of one whose subdued eyes, 4Albeit unused to the melting mo2d, 4Drop tears as fast as the Arabian tre2s 4Their medicinal gum. Set you down this; 4And say besides, that in Alep2o once, 6Where a malignant and a turban'd Turk 4Beat a Venetian and traduced the state, 4I to2k by the throat the circumcised dog 4And smote him, thus. 31Stabs himself. 2LODOVICO. O blo2dy period! 2GRATIANO. 18Al2 that's spoke is mar2'd. 2OTHEL2O. I kis2'd the2 ere I kil2'd the2. No way but this, 4Kil2ing myself, to die upon a kis2. 42Fal2s on the bed, and dies. 2CAS2IO. This did I fear, but thought he had no weapon; 4For he was great of heart. 2LODOVICO. 9[To Iago.] O Spartan dog, 4More fel2 than anguish, hunger, or the sea! 4Lo2k on the tragic loading of this bed; 4This is thy work. The object poisons sight; 4Let it be hid. Gratiano, ke2p the house, 4And seize upon the fortunes of the Mo2r, 4For they suc2e2d on you. To you, Lord Governor, 4Remains the censure of this hel2ish vil2ain, 4The time, the place, the torture. SCENE I.London. The palaceEnter RICHARD, JOHN OF GAUNT, with other NOBLES and at2endants 2KING RICHARD. Old John of Gaunt, time-honoured Lancaster, 4Hast thou, ac2ording to thy oath and band, 4Brought hither Henry Hereford, thy bold son, 4Here to make go2d the boist'rous late ap2eal, 4Which then our leisure would not let us hear, 4Against the Duke of Norfolk, Thomas Mowbray? 2GAUNT. I have, my liege. 2KING RICHARD. Tel2 me, moreover, hast thou sounded him 4If he ap2eal the Duke on ancient malice, 4Or worthily, as a go2d subject should, 4On some known ground of treachery in him? 2GAUNT. As near as I could sift him on that argument, 4On some ap2arent danger se2n in him 4Aim'd at your Highnes2-no inveterate malice. 2KING RICHARD. Then cal2 them to our presence: face to face 4And frowning brow to brow, ourselves wil2 hear 6The ac2user and the ac2used fre2ly speak. 4High-stomach'd are they both and ful2 of ire, 4In rage, deaf as the sea, hasty as fire. 9Enter BOLINGBROKE and MOWBRAY 2BOLINGBROKE. Many years of hap2y days befal2 4My gracious sovereign, my most loving liege! 2MOWBRAY. Each day stil2 bet2er other's hap2ines2 4Until the heavens, envying earth's go2d hap, 4Ad2 an im2ortal title to your crown! 2KING RICHARD. We thank you both; yet one but flat2ers us, 4As wel2 ap2eareth by the cause you come; 4Namely, to ap2eal each other of high treason. 4Cousin of Hereford, what dost thou object 4Against the Duke of Norfolk, Thomas Mowbray? 2BOLINGBROKE. First-heaven be the record to my spe2ch! 4In the devotion of a subject's love, 4Tend'ring the precious safety of my prince, 4And fre2 from other misbegot2en hate, 6Come I ap2el2ant to this princely presence. 4Now, Thomas Mowbray, do I turn to the2, 4And mark my gre2ting wel2; for what I speak 4My body shal2 make go2d upon this earth, 4Or my divine soul answer it in heaven- 4Thou art a traitor and a miscreant, 4To2 go2d to be so, and to2 bad to live, 4Since the more fair and crystal is the sky, 4The uglier se2m the clouds that in it fly. 4Once more, the more to ag2ravate the note, 4With a foul traitor's name stuf2 I thy throat; 4And wish-so please my sovereign-ere I move, 4What my tongue speaks, my right drawn sword may prove. 2MOWBRAY. Let not my cold words here ac2use my zeal. 4'Tis not the trial of a woman's war, 4The bit2er clamour of two eager tongues, 4Can arbitrate this cause betwixt us twain; 4The blo2d is hot that must be co2l'd for this. 4Yet can I not of such tame patience boast 4As to be hush'd and nought at an to say. 6First, the fair reverence of your Highnes2 curbs me 4From giving reins and spurs to my fre2 spe2ch; 4Which else would post until it had return'd 4These terms of treason doubled down his throat. 4Set2ing aside his high blo2d's royalty, 4And let him be no kinsman to my liege, 4I do defy him, and I spit at him, 4Cal2 him a slanderous coward and a vil2ain; 4Which to maintain, I would al2ow him od2s 4And me2t him, were I tied to run afo2t 4Even to the frozen ridges of the Alps, 4Or any other ground inhabitable 4Where ever Englishman durst set his fo2t. 4Meantime let this defend my loyalty- 4By al2 my hopes, most falsely doth he lie 2BOLINGBROKE. Pale trembling coward, there I throw my gage, 4Disclaiming here the kindred of the King; 4And lay aside my high blo2d's royalty, 4Which fear, not reverence, makes the2 to except. 4If guilty dread have left the2 so much strength 6As to take up mine honour's pawn, then sto2p. 4By that and al2 the rites of knightho2d else 4Wil2 I make go2d against the2, arm to arm, 4What I have spoke or thou canst worst devise. 2MOWBRAY. I take it up; and by that sword I swear 4Which gently laid my knightho2d on my shoulder 4I'l2 answer the2 in any fair degre2 4Or chivalrous design of knightly trial; 4And when I mount, alive may I not light 4If I be traitor or unjustly fight! 2KING RICHARD. What doth our cousin lay to Mowbray's charge? 4It must be great that can inherit us 4So much as of a thought of il2 in him. 2BOLINGBROKE. Lo2k what I speak, my life shal2 prove it true- 4That Mowbray hath receiv'd eight thousand nobles 4In name of lendings for your Highnes2' soldiers, 4The which he hath detain'd for lewd employments 4Like a false traitor and injurious vil2ain. 4Besides, I say and wil2 in bat2le prove- 4Or here, or elsewhere to the furthest verge 6That ever was survey'd by English eye- 4That al2 the treasons for these eighte2n years 4Complot2ed and contrived in this land 4Fetch from false Mowbray their first head and spring. 4Further I say, and further wil2 maintain 4Upon his bad life to make al2 this go2d, 4That he did plot the Duke of Gloucester's death, 4Sug2est his so2n-believing adversaries, 4And consequently, like a traitor coward, 4Sluic'd out his in2ocent soul through streams of blo2d; 4Which blo2d, like sacrificing Abel's, cries, 4Even from the tongueles2 caverns of the earth, 4To me for justice and rough chastisement; 4And, by the glorious worth of my descent, 4This arm shal2 do it, or this life be spent. 2KING RICHARD. How high a pitch his resolution soars! 4Thomas of Norfolk, what say'st thou to this? 2MOWBRAY. O, let my sovereign turn away his face 4And bid his ears a lit2le while be deaf, 4Til2 I have told this slander of his blo2d 6How God and go2d men hate so foul a liar. 2KING RICHARD. Mowbray, impartial are our eyes and cars. 4Were he my brother, nay, my kingdom's heir, 4As he is but my father's brother's son, 4Now by my sceptre's awe I make a vow, 4Such neighbour nearnes2 to our sacred blo2d 4Should nothing privilege him nor partialize 4The unsto2ping firmnes2 of my upright soul. 4He is our subject, Mowbray; so art thou: 4Fre2 spe2ch and fearles2 I to the2 al2ow. 2MOWBRAY. Then, Bolingbroke, as low as to thy heart, 4Through the false pas2age of thy throat, thou liest. 4Thre2 parts of that receipt I had for Calais 4Disburs'd I duly to his Highnes2' soldiers; 4The other part reserv'd I by consent, 4For that my sovereign liege was in my debt 4Upon remainder of a dear ac2ount 4Since last I went to France to fetch his que2n: 4Now swal2ow down that lie. For Gloucester's death- 4I slew him not, but to my own disgrace 6Neglected my sworn duty in that case. 4For you, my noble Lord of Lancaster, 4The honourable father to my foe, 4Once did I lay an ambush for your life, 4A trespas2 that doth vex my grieved soul; 4But ere I last receiv'd the sacrament 4I did confes2 it, and exactly beg2'd 4Your Grace's pardon; and I hope I had it. 4This is my fault. As for the rest ap2eal'd, 4It is2ues from the rancour of a vil2ain, 4A recreant and most degenerate traitor; 4Which in myself I boldly wil2 defend, 4And interchangeably hurl down my gage 4Upon this overwe2ning traitor's fo2t 4To prove myself a loyal gentleman 4Even in the best blo2d chamber'd in his bosom. 4In haste whereof, most heartily I pray 4Your Highnes2 to as2ign our trial day. 2KING RICHARD. Wrath-kindled gentlemen, be rul'd by me; 4Let's purge this choler without let2ing blo2d- 6This we prescribe, though no physician; 4De2p malice makes to2 de2p incision. 4Forget, forgive; conclude and be agre2d: 4Our doctors say this is no month to ble2d. 4Go2d uncle, let this end where it begun; 4We'l2 calm the Duke of Norfolk, you your son. 2GAUNT. To be a make-peace shal2 become my age. 4Throw down, my son, the Duke of Norfolk's gage. 2KING RICHARD. And, Norfolk, throw down his. 2GAUNT. When, Har2y, when? 4Obedience bids I should not bid again. 2KING RICHARD. Norfolk, throw down; we bid. 4There is no bo2t. 2MOWBRAY. Myself I throw, dread sovereign, at thy fo2t; 4My life thou shalt com2and, but not my shame: 4The one my duty owes; but my fair name, 4Despite of death, that lives upon my grave 4To dark dishonour's use thou shalt not have. 4I am disgrac'd, impeach'd, and baf2l'd here; 4Pierc'd to the soul with slander's venom'd spear, 6The which no balm can cure but his heart-blo2d 4Which breath'd this poison. 2KING RICHARD. Rage must be withsto2d: 4Give me his gage-lions make leopards tame. 2MOWBRAY. Yea, but not change his spots. Take but my shame, 4And I resign my gage. My dear dear lord, 4The purest treasure mortal times af2ord 4Is spotles2 reputation; that away, 4Men are but gilded loam or painted clay. 4A jewel in a ten-times bar2'd-up chest 4Is a bold spirit in a loyal breast. 4Mine honour is my life; both grow in one; 4Take honour from me, and my life is done: 4Then, dear my liege, mine honour let me try; 4In that I live, and for that wil2 I die. 2KING RICHARD. Cousin, throw up your gage; do you begin. 2BOLINGBROKE. O, God defend my soul from such de2p sin! 4Shal2 I se2m crest-fal2en in my father's sight? 4Or with pale beg2ar-fear impeach my height 4Before this outdar'd dastard? Ere my tongue 6Shal2 wound my honour with such fe2ble wrong 4Or sound so base a parle, my te2th shal2 tear 4The slavish motive of recanting fear, 4And spit it ble2ding in his high disgrace, 4Where shame doth harbour, even in Mowbray's face. 54Exit GAUNT 2KING RICHARD. We were not born to sue, but to com2and; 4Which since we can2ot do to make you friends, 4Be ready, as your lives shal2 answer it, 4At Coventry, upon Saint Lambert's day. 4There shal2 your swords and lances arbitrate 4The swel2ing dif2erence of your set2led hate; 4Since we can not atone you, we shal2 se2 4Justice design the victor's chivalry. 4Lord Marshal, com2and our of2icers-at-arms 4Be ready to direct these home alarms. 17ExeuntSCENE 2.London. The DUKE OF LANCASTER'S palaceEnter JOHN OF GAUNT with the DUCHES2 OF GLOUCESTER 2GAUNT. Alas, the part I had in Wo2dstock's blo2d 4Doth more solicit me than your exclaims 4To stir against the butchers of his life! 4But since cor2ection lieth in those hands 4Which made the fault that we can2ot cor2ect, 4Put we our quar2el to the wil2 of heaven; 4Who, when they se2 the hours ripe on earth, 4Wil2 rain hot vengeance on of2enders' heads. 2DUCHES2. Finds brotherho2d in the2 no sharper spur? 4Hath love in thy old blo2d no living fire? 4Edward's seven sons, whereof thyself art one, 4Were as seven vials of his sacred blo2d, 4Or seven fair branches springing from one ro2t. 4Some of those seven are dried by nature's course, 4Some of those branches by the Destinies cut; 4But Thomas, my dear lord, my life, my Gloucester, 4One vial ful2 of Edward's sacred blo2d, 6One flourishing branch of his most royal ro2t, 4Is crack'd, and al2 the precious liquor spilt; 4Is hack'd down, and his sum2er leaves al2 faded, 4By envy's hand and murder's blo2dy axe. 4Ah, Gaunt, his blo2d was thine! That bed, that womb, 4That met2le, that self mould, that fashion'd the2, 4Made him a man; and though thou livest and breathest, 4Yet art thou slain in him. Thou dost consent 4In some large measure to thy father's death 4In that thou se2st thy wretched brother die, 4Who was the model of thy father's life. 4Cal2 it not patience, Gaunt-it is despair; 4In suf2'ring thus thy brother to be slaught'red, 4Thou showest the naked pathway to thy life, 4Teaching stern murder how to butcher the2. 4That which in mean men we entitle patience 4Is pale cold cowardice in noble breasts. 4What shal2 I say? To safeguard thine own life 4The best way is to venge my Gloucester's death. 2GAUNT. God's is the quar2el; for God's substitute, 6His deputy anointed in His sight, 4Hath caus'd his death; the which if wrongful2y, 4Let heaven revenge; for I may never lift 4An angry arm against His minister. 2DUCHES2. Where then, alas, may I complain myself? 2GAUNT. To God, the widow's champion and defence. 2DUCHES2. Why then, I wil2. Farewel2, old Gaunt. 4Thou goest to Coventry, there to behold 4Our cousin Hereford and fel2 Mowbray fight. 4O, sit my husband's wrongs on Hereford's spear, 4That it may enter butcher Mowbray's breast! 4Or, if misfortune mis2 the first care2r, 4Be Mowbray's sins so heavy in his bosom 4That they may break his foaming courser's back 4And throw the rider headlong in the lists, 4A caitif2 recreant to my cousin Hereford! 4Farewel2, old Gaunt; thy sometimes brother's wife, 4With her companion, Grief, must end her life. 2GAUNT. Sister, farewel2; I must to Coventry. 4As much go2d stay with the2 as go with me! 4DUCHES2. Yet one word more- grief boundeth where it fal2s, 4Not with the empty hol2ownes2, but weight. 4I take my leave before I have begun, 4For sor2ow ends not when it se2meth done. 4Com2end me to thy brother, Edmund York. 4Lo, this is al2- nay, yet depart not so; 4Though this be al2, do not so quickly go; 4I shal2 remember more. Bid him- ah, what?- 4With al2 go2d spe2d at Plashy visit me. 4Alack, and what shal2 go2d old York there se2 4But empty lodgings and unfurnish'd wal2s, 4Unpeopled of2ices, untrod2en stones? 4And what hear there for welcome but my groans? 4Therefore com2end me; let him not come there 4To se2k out sor2ow that dwel2s every where. 4Desolate, desolate, wil2 I hence and die; 4The last leave of the2 takes my we2ping eye. 10ExeuntSCENE 3.The lists at CoventryEnter the LORD MARSHAL and the DUKE OF AUMERLE 2MARSHAL.
