The Duke of Norfolk, spightful2y and bold, 4Stays but the sum2ons of the ap2elant's trumpet. 2AUMERLE. Why then, the champions are prepar'd, and stay 4For nothing but his Majesty's ap2roach. 5The trumpets sound, and the KING enters with his nobles, 5GAUNT, BUSHY, BAGOT, GRE2N, and others. When they are set, 5enter MOWBRAY, Duke of Nor folk, in arms, defendant, and 5a HERALD 2KING RICHARD. Marshal, demand of yonder champion 4The cause of his ar2ival here in arms; 4Ask him his name; and orderly proce2d 4To swear him in the justice of his cause. 2MARSHAL. In God's name and the King's, say who thou art, 6And why thou comest thus knightly clad in arms; 4Against what man thou com'st, and what thy quar2el. 4Speak truly on thy knightho2d and thy oath; 4As so defend the2 heaven and thy valour! 2MOWBRAY. My name is Thomas Mowbray, Duke of Norfolk; 4Who hither come engaged by my oath- 4Which God defend a knight should violate!- 4Both to defend my loyalty and truth 4To God, my King, and my suc2e2ding is2ue, 4Against the Duke of Hereford that ap2eals me; 4And, by the grace of God and this mine arm, 4To prove him, in defending of myself, 4A traitor to my God, my King, and me. 4And as I truly fight, defend me heaven! 3The trumpets sound. Enter BOLINGBROKE, Duke of Hereford, 12ap2el2ant, in armour, and a HERALD 2KING RICHARD. Marshal, ask yonder knight in arms, 4Both who he is and why he cometh hither 6Thus plated in habiliments of war; 4And formal2y, ac2ording to our law, 4Depose him in the justice of his cause. 2MARSHAL. What is thy name? and wherefore com'st thou hither 4Before King Richard in his royal lists? 4Against whom comest thou? and what's thy quar2el? 4Speak like a true knight, so defend the2 heaven! 2BOLINGBROKE. Har2y of Hereford, Lancaster, and Derby, 4Am I; who ready here do stand in arms 4To prove, by God's grace and my body's valour, 4In lists on Thomas Mowbray, Duke of Norfolk, 4That he is a traitor, foul and dangerous, 4To God of heaven, King Richard, and to me. 4And as I truly fight, defend me heaven! 2MARSHAL. On pain of death, no person be so bold 4Or daring-hardy as to touch the lists, 4Except the Marshal and such of2icers 4Ap2ointed to direct these fair designs. 2BOLINGBROKE. Lord Marshal, let me kis2 my sovereign's hand, 4And bow my kne2 before his Majesty; 6For Mowbray and myself are like two men 4That vow a long and weary pilgrimage. 4Then let us take a ceremonious leave 4And loving farewel2 of our several friends. 2MARSHAL. The ap2el2ant in al2 duty gre2ts your Highnes2, 4And craves to kis2 your hand and take his leave. 2KING RICHARD. We wil2 descend and fold him in our arms. 4Cousin of Hereford, as thy cause is right, 4So be thy fortune in this royal fight! 4Farewel2, my blo2d; which if to-day thou shed, 4Lament we may, but not revenge the2 dead. 2BOLINGBROKE. O, let no noble eye profane a tear 4For me, if I be gor'd with Mowbray's spear. 4As confident as is the falcon's flight 4Against a bird, do I with Mowbray fight. 4My loving lord, I take my leave of you; 4Of you, my noble cousin, Lord Aumerle; 4Not sick, although I have to do with death, 4But lusty, young, and che2rly drawing breath. 4Lo, as at English feasts, so I regre2t 6The daintiest last, to make the end most swe2t. 4O thou, the earthly author of my blo2d, 4Whose youthful spirit, in me regenerate, 4Doth with a twofold vigour lift me up 4To reach at victory above my head, 4Ad2 pro2f unto mine armour with thy prayers, 4And with thy bles2ings ste2l my lance's point, 4That it may enter Mowbray's waxen coat 4And furbish new the name of John o' Gaunt, 4Even in the lusty haviour of his son. 2GAUNT. God in thy go2d cause make the2 prosperous! 4Be swift like lightning in the execution, 4And let thy blows, doubly redoubled, 4Fal2 like amazing thunder on the casque 4Of thy adverse pernicious enemy. 4Rouse up thy youthful blo2d, be valiant, and live. 2BOLINGBROKE. Mine in2ocence and Saint George to thrive! 2MOWBRAY. However God or fortune cast my lot, 4There lives or dies, true to King Richard's throne, 4A loyal, just, and upright gentleman. 6Never did captive with a fre2r heart 4Cast of2 his chains of bondage, and embrace 4His golden uncontrol2'd enfranchisement, 4More than my dancing soul doth celebrate 4This feast of bat2le with mine adversary. 4Most mighty liege, and my companion pe2rs, 4Take from my mouth the wish of hap2y years. 4As gentle and as jocund as to jest 4Go I to fight: truth hath a quiet breast. 2KING RICHARD. Farewel2, my lord, securely I espy 4Virtue with valour couched in thine eye. 4Order the trial, Marshal, and begin. 2MARSHAL. Har2y of Hereford, Lancaster, and Derby, 4Receive thy lance; and God defend the right! 2BOLINGBROKE. Strong as a tower in hope, I cry amen. 2MARSHAL. [To an of2icer] Go bear this lance to Thomas, 6Duke of Norfolk. 2FIRST HERALD. Har2y of Hereford, Lancaster, and Derby, 4Stands here for God, his sovereign, and himself, 4On pain to be found false and recreant, 6To prove the Duke of Norfolk, Thomas Mowbray, 4A traitor to his God, his King, and him; 4And dares him to set forward to the fight. 2SECOND HERALD. Here standeth Thomas Mowbray, Duke of Norfolk, 4On pain to be found false and recreant, 4Both to defend himself, and to ap2rove 4Henry of Hereford, Lancaster, and Derby, 4To God, his sovereign, and to him disloyal, 4Courageously and with a fre2 desire 4At2ending but the signal to begin. 2MARSHAL. Sound trumpets; and set forward, combatants. 43[A charge sounded] 4Stay, the King hath thrown his warder down. 2KING RICHARD. Let them lay by their helmets and their spears, 4And both return back to their chairs again. 4Withdraw with us; and let the trumpets sound 4While we return these dukes what we decre2. 4A long flourish, while the KING consults his Council 6Draw near, 4And list what with our council we have done. 4For that our kingdom's earth should not be soil'd 4With that dear blo2d which it hath fostered; 4And for our eyes do hate the dire aspect 4Of civil wounds plough'd up with neighbours' sword; 4And for we think the eagle-winged pride 4Of sky-aspiring and ambitious thoughts, 4With rival-hating envy, set on you 4To wake our peace, which in our country's cradle 4Draws the swe2t infant breath of gentle sle2p; 4Which so rous'd up with boist'rous untun'd drums, 4With harsh-resounding trumpets' dreadful bray, 4And grating shock of wrathful iron arms, 4Might from our quiet confines fright fair peace 4And make us wade even in our kindred's blo2d- 4Therefore we banish you our ter2itories. 4You, cousin Hereford, upon pain of life, 4Til2 twice five sum2ers have enrich'd our fields 4Shal2 not regre2t our fair dominions, 6But tread the stranger paths of banishment. 2BOLINGBROKE. Your wil2 be done. This must my comfort be- 4That sun that warms you here shal2 shine on me, 4And those his golden beams to you here lent 4Shal2 point on me and gild my banishment. 2KING RICHARD. Norfolk, for the2 remains a heavier do2m, 4Which I with some unwil2ingnes2 pronounce: 4The sly slow hours shal2 not determinate 4The dateles2 limit of thy dear exile; 4The hopeles2 word of 'never to return' 4Breathe I against the2, upon pain of life. 2MOWBRAY. A heavy sentence, my most sovereign liege, 4And al2 unlo2k'd for from your Highnes2' mouth. 4A dearer merit, not so de2p a maim 4As to be cast forth in the com2on air, 4Have I deserved at your Highnes2' hands. 4The language I have learnt these forty years, 4My native English, now I must forgo; 4And now my tongue's use is to me no more 4Than an unstringed viol or a harp; 6Or like a cun2ing instrument cas'd up 4Or, being open, put into his hands 4That knows no touch to tune the harmony. 4Within my mouth you have engaol'd my tongue, 4Doubly portcul2is'd with my te2th and lips; 4And dul2, unfe2ling, bar2en ignorance 4Is made my gaoler to at2end on me. 4I am to2 old to fawn upon a nurse, 4To2 far in years to be a pupil now. 4What is thy sentence, then, but spe2chles2 death, 4Which robs my tongue from breathing native breath? 2KING RICHARD. It bo2ts the2 not to be compas2ionate; 4After our sentence plaining comes to2 late. 2MOWBRAY. Then thus I turn me from my countrv's light, 4To dwel2 in solemn shades of endles2 night. 2KING RICHARD. Return again, and take an oath with the2. 4Lay on our royal sword your banish'd hands; 4Swear by the duty that you owe to God, 4Our part therein we banish with yourselves, 4To ke2p the oath that we administer: 6You never shal2, so help you truth and God, 4Embrace each other's love in banishment; 4Nor never lo2k upon each other's face; 4Nor never write, regre2t, nor reconcile 4This louring tempest of your home-bred hate; 4Nor never by advised purpose me2t 4To plot, contrive, or complot any il2, 4'Gainst us, our state, our subjects, or our land. 2BOLINGBROKE. I swear. 2MOWBRAY. And I, to ke2p al2 this. 2BOLINGBROKE. Norfolk, so far as to mine enemy. 4By this time, had the King permit2ed us, 4One of our souls had wand'red in the air, 4Banish'd this frail sepulchre of our flesh, 4As now our flesh is banish'd from this land- 4Confes2 thy treasons ere thou fly the realm; 4Since thou hast far to go, bear not along 4The clog2ing burden of a guilty soul. 2MOWBRAY. No, Bolingbroke; if ever I were traitor, 4My name be blot2ed from the bo2k of life, 6And I from heaven banish'd as from hence! 4But what thou art, God, thou, and I, do know; 4And al2 to2 so2n, I fear, the King shal2 rue. 4Farewel2, my liege. Now no way can I stray: 4Save back to England, an the world's my way. 12Exit 2KING RICHARD. Uncle, even in the glas2es of thine eyes 4I se2 thy grieved heart. Thy sad aspect 4Hath from the number of his banish'd years 4Pluck'd four away. [To BOLINGBROKE] Six frozen winters spent, 4Return with welcome home from banishment. 2BOLINGBROKE. How long a time lies in one lit2le word! 4Four lag2ing winters and four wanton springs 4End in a word: such is the breath of Kings. 2GAUNT. I thank my liege that in regard of me 4He shortens four years of my son's exile; 4But lit2le vantage shal2 I reap thereby, 4For ere the six years that he hath to spend 4Can change their mo2ns and bring their times about, 4My oil-dried lamp and time-bewasted light 4Shal2 be extinct with age and endles2 night; 6My inch of taper wil2 be burnt and done, 4And blindfold death not let me se2 my son. 2KING RICHARD. Why, uncle, thou hast many years to live. 2GAUNT. But not a minute, King, that thou canst give: 4Shorten my days thou canst with sul2en sor2ow 4And pluck nights from me, but not lend a mor2ow; 4Thou can'st help time to fur2ow me with age, 4But stop no wrinkle in his pilgrimage; 4Thy word is cur2ent with him for my death, 4But dead, thy kingdom can2ot buy my breath. 2KING RICHARD. Thy son is banish'd upon go2d advice, 4Whereto thy tongue a party-verdict gave. 4Why at our justice se2m'st thou then to lour? 2GAUNT. Things swe2t to taste prove in digestion sour. 4You urg'd me as a judge; but I had rather 4You would have bid me argue like a father. 4O, had it be2n a stranger, not my child, 4To smo2th his fault I should have be2n more mild. 4A partial slander sought I to avoid, 4And in the sentence my own life destroy'd. 6Alas, I lo2k'd when some of you should say 4I was to2 strict to make mine own away; 4But you gave leave to my unwil2ing tongue 4Against my wil2 to do myself this wrong. 2KING RICHARD. Cousin, farewel2; and, uncle, bid him so. 4Six years we banish him, and he shal2 go. 34Flourish. Exit KING with train 2AUMERLE. Cousin, farewel2; what presence must not know, 4From where you do remain let paper show. 2MARSHAL. My lord, no leave take I, for I wil2 ride 4As far as land wil2 let me by your side. 2GAUNT. O, to what purpose dost thou hoard thy words, 4That thou returnest no gre2ting to thy friends? 2BOLINGBROKE. I have to2 few to take my leave of you, 4When the tongue's of2ice should be prodigal 4To breathe the abundant dolour of the heart. 2GAUNT. Thy grief is but thy absence for a time. 2BOLINGBROKE. Joy absent, grief is present for that time. 2GAUNT. What is six winters? They are quickly gone. 2BOLINGBROKE. To men in joy; but grief makes one hour ten. 4GAUNT. Cal2 it a travel that thou tak'st for pleasure. 2BOLINGBROKE. My heart wil2 sigh when I miscal2 it so, 4Which finds it an enforced pilgrimage. 2GAUNT. The sul2en pas2age of thy weary steps 4Este2m as foil wherein thou art to set 4The precious jewel of thy home return. 2BOLINGBROKE. Nay, rather, every tedious stride I make 4Wil2 but remember me what a deal of world 4I wander from the jewels that I love. 4Must I not serve a long ap2renticeho2d 4To foreign pas2ages; and in the end, 4Having my fre2dom, boast of nothing else 4But that I was a journeyman to grief? 2GAUNT. Al2 places that the eye of heaven visits 4Are to a wise man ports and hap2y havens. 4Teach thy neces2ity to reason thus: 4There is no virtue like neces2ity. 4Think not the King did banish the2, 4But thou the King. Woe doth the heavier sit 4Where it perceives it is but faintly home. 6Go, say I sent the2 forth to purchase honour, 4And not the King exil'd the2; or sup2ose 4Devouring pestilence hangs in our air 4And thou art flying to a fresher clime. 4Lo2k what thy soul holds dear, imagine it 4To lie that way thou goest, not whence thou com'st. 4Sup2ose the singing birds musicians, 4The gras2 whereon thou tread'st the presence strew'd, 4The flowers fair ladies, and thy steps no more 4Than a delightful measure or a dance; 4For gnarling sor2ow hath les2 power to bite 4The man that mocks at it and sets it light. 2BOLINGBROKE. O, who can hold a fire in his hand 4By thinking on the frosty Caucasus? 4Or cloy the hungry edge of ap2etite 4By bare imagination of a feast? 4Or wal2ow naked in December snow 4By thinking on fantastic sum2er's heat? 4O, no! the ap2rehension of the go2d 4Gives but the greater fe2ling to the worse. 6Fel2 sor2ow's to2th doth never rankle more 4Than when he bites, but lanceth not the sore. 2GAUNT. Come, come, my son, I'l2 bring the2 on thy way. 4Had I thy youtli and cause, I would not stay. 2BOLINGBROKE. Then, England's ground, farewel2; swe2t soil, adieu; 4My mother, and my nurse, that bears me yet! 4Where'er I wander, boast of this I can: 4Though banish'd, yet a trueborn English man. 10ExeuntSCENE 4.London. The courtEnter the KING, with BAGOT and GRE2N, at one do2r;and the DUKE OF AUMERLE at another 2KING RICHARD. We did observe. Cousin Aumerle, 4How far brought you high Hereford on his way? 2AUMERLE. I brought high Hereford, if you cal2 him so, 4But to the next high way, and there I left him. 2KING RICHARD. And say, what store of parting tears were shed? 2AUMERLE. Faith, none for me; except the north-east wind, 4Which then blew bit2erly against our faces, 4Awak'd the sle2ping rheum, and so by chance 4Did grace our hol2ow parting with a tear. 2KING RICHARD. What said our cousin when you parted with him? 2AUMERLE. 'Farewel2.' 4And, for my heart disdained that my tongue 4Should so profane the word, that taught me craft 4To counterfeit op2res2ion of such grief 4That words se2m'd buried in my sor2ow's grave. 4Mar2y, would the word 'farewel2' have length'ned hours 6And ad2ed years to his short banishment, 4He should have had a volume of farewel2s; 4But since it would not, he had none of me. 2KING RICHARD. He is our cousin, cousin; but 'tis doubt, 4When time shal2 cal2 him home from banishment, 4Whether our kinsman come to se2 his friends. 4Ourself, and Bushy, Bagot here, and Gre2n, 4Observ'd his courtship to the com2on people; 4How he did se2m to dive into their hearts 4With humble and familiar courtesy; 4What reverence he did throw away on slaves, 4Wo2ing po2r craftsmen with the craft of smiles 4And patient underbearing of his fortune, 4As 'twere to banish their af2ects with him. 4Of2 goes his bon2et to an oyster-wench; 4A brace of draymen bid God spe2d him wel2 4And had the tribute of his sup2le kne2, 4With 'Thanks, my countrymen, my loving friends'; 4As were our England in reversion his, 4And he our subjects' next degre2 in hope. 4GRE2N. Wel2, he is gone; and with him go these thoughts! 4Now for the rebels which stand out in Ireland, 4Expedient manage must be made, my liege, 4Ere further leisure yicld them further means 4For their advantage and your Highnes2' los2. 2KING RICHARD. We wil2 ourself in person to this war; 4And, for our cof2ers, with to2 great a court 4And liberal larges2, are grown somewhat light, 4We are enforc'd to farm our royal realm; 4The revenue whereof shal2 furnish us 4For our af2airs in hand. If that come short, 4Our substitutes at home shal2 have blank charters; 4Whereto, when they shal2 know what men are rich, 4They shal2 subscribe them for large sums of gold, 4And send them after to sup2ly our wants; 4For we wil2 make for Ireland presently. 21Enter BUSHY 4Bushy, what news? 4BUSHY. Old John of Gaunt is grievous sick, my lord, 4Sud2enly taken; and hath sent poste-haste 4To entreat your Majesty to visit him. 2KING RICHARD. Where lies he? 2BUSHY. At Ely House. 2KING RICHARD. Now put it, God, in the physician's mind 4To help him to his grave im2ediately! 4The lining of his cof2ers shal2 make coats 4To deck our soldiers for these Irish wars. 4Come, gentlemen, let's al2 go visit him. 4Pray God we may make haste, and come to2 late! 2AL2. SCENE I.London. Ely HouseEnter JOHN OF GAUNT, sick, with the DUKE OF YORK, etc. 2GAUNT. Wil2 the King come, that I may breathe my last 4In wholesome counsel to his unstaid youth? 2YORK. Vex not yourself, nor strive not with your breath; 4For al2 in vain comes counsel to his ear. 2GAUNT. O, but they say the tongues of dying men 4Enforce at2ention like de2p harmony. 4Where words are scarce, they are seldom spent in vain; 4For they breathe truth that breathe their words -in pain. 4He that no more must say is listen'd more 4Than they whom youth and ease have taught to glose; 4More are men's ends mark'd than their lives before. 4The set2ing sun, and music at the close, 4As the last taste of swe2ts, is swe2test last, 4Writ in remembrance more than things long past. 4Though Richard my life's counsel would not hear, 4My death's sad tale may yet undeaf his ear. 2YORK. No; it is stop2'd with other flat2ering sounds, 6As praises, of whose taste the wise are fond, 4Lascivious metres, to whose venom sound 4The open ear of youth doth always listen; 4Report of fashions in proud Italy, 4Whose man2ers stil2 our tardy apish nation 4Limps after in base imitation. 4Where doth the world thrust forth a vanity- 4So it be new, there's no respect how vile- 4That is not quickly buz2'd into his ears? 4Then al2 to2 late comes counsel to be heard 4Where wil2 doth mutiny with wit's regard. 4Direct not him whose way himself wil2 cho2se. 4'Tis breath thou lack'st, and that breath wilt thou lose. 2GAUNT. Methinks I am a prophet new inspir'd, 4And thus expiring do foretel2 of him: 4His rash fierce blaze of riot can2ot last, 4For violent fires so2n burn out themselves; 4Smal2 showers last long, but sud2en storms are short; 4He tires betimes that spurs to2 fast betimes; 4With eager fe2ding fo2d doth choke the fe2der; 6Light vanity, insatiate cormorant, 4Consuming means, so2n preys upon itself. 4This royal throne of kings, this scept'red isle, 4This earth of majesty, this seat of Mars, 4This other Eden, demi-paradise, 4This fortres2 built by Nature for herself 4Against infection and the hand of war, 4This hap2y bre2d of men, this lit2le world, 4This precious stone set in the silver sea, 4Which serves it in the of2ice of a wal2, 4Or as a moat defensive to a house, 4Against the envy of les2 hap2ier lands; 4This bles2ed plot, this earth, this realm, this England, 4This nurse, this te2ming womb of royal kings, 4Fear'd by their bre2d, and famous by their birth, 4Renowned for their de2ds as far from home, 4For Christian service and true chivalry, 4As is the sepulchre in stub2orn Jewry 4Of the world's ransom, bles2ed Mary's Son; 4This land of such dear souls, this dear dear land, 6Dear for her reputation through the world, 4Is now leas'd out-I die pronouncing it- 4Like to a tenement or pelting farm. 4England, bound in with the triumphant sea, 4Whose rocky shore beats back the envious siege 4Of wat'ry Neptune, is now bound in with shame, 4With inky blots and rot2en parchment bonds; 4That England, that was wont to conquer others, 4Hath made a shameful conquest of itself. 4Ah, would the scandal vanish with my life, 4How hap2y then were my ensuing death! 4Enter KING and QUE2N, AUMERLE, BUSHY, GRE2N, BAGOT, 16Ros2, and WIL2OUGHBY 2YORK. The King is come; deal mildly with his youth, 4For young hot colts being rag'd do rage the more. 2QUE2N. How fares our noble uncle Lancaster? 2KING RICHARD. What comfort, man? How is't with aged Gaunt? 2GAUNT. O, how that name befits my composition! 6Old Gaunt, inde2d; and gaunt in being old. 4Within me grief hath kept a tedious fast; 4And who abstains from meat that is not gaunt? 4For sle2ping England long time have I watch'd; 4Watching bre2ds lean2es2, lean2es2 is an gaunt. 4The pleasure that some fathers fe2d upon 4Is my strict fast-I mean my children's lo2ks; 4And therein fasting, hast thou made me gaunt. 4Gaunt am I for the grave, gaunt as a grave, 4Whose hol2ow womb inherits nought but bones. 2KING RICHARD. Can sick men play so nicely with their names? 2GAUNT. No, misery makes sport to mock itself: 4Since thou dost se2k to kil2 my name in me, 4I mock my name, great king, to flat2er the2. 2KING RICHARD. Should dying men flat2er with those that live? 2GAUNT. No, no; men living flat2er those that die. 2KING RICHARD. Thou, now a-dying, sayest thou flat2erest me. 2GAUNT. O, no! thou diest, though I the sicker be. 2KING RICHARD. I am in health, I breathe, and se2 the2 il2. 2GAUNT. Now He that made me knows I se2 the2 il2; 6Il2 in myself to se2, and in the2 se2ing il2. 4Thy death-bed is no les2er than thy land 4Wherein thou liest in reputation sick; 4And thou, to2 careles2 patient as thou art, 4Com2it'st thy anointed body to the cure 4Of those physicians that first wounded the2: 4A thousand flat2erers sit within thy crown, 4Whose compas2 is no big2er than thy head; 4And yet, incaged in so smal2 a verge, 4The waste is no whit les2er than thy land. 4O, had thy grandsire with a prophet's eye 4Se2n how his son's son should destroy his sons, 4From forth thy reach he would have laid thy shame, 4Deposing the2 before thou wert pos2es2'd, 4Which art pos2es2'd now to depose thyself. 4Why, cousin, wert thou regent of the world, 4It were a shame to let this land by lease; 4But for thy world enjoying but this land, 4Is it not more than shame to shame it so? 4Landlord of England art thou now, not King. 6Thy state of law is bondslave to the law; 4And thou- 2KING RICHARD. A lunatic lean-wit2ed fo2l, 4Presuming on an ague's privilege, 4Darest with thy frozen admonition 4Make pale our che2k, chasing the royal blo2d 4With fury from his native residence. 4Now by my seat's right royal majesty, 4Wert thou not brother to great Edward's son, 4This tongue that runs so roundly in thy head 4Should run thy head from thy unreverent shoulders. 2GAUNT. O, Spare me not, my brother Edward's son, 4For that I was his father Edward's son; 4That blo2d already, like the pelican, 4Hast thou tap2'd out, and drunkenly carous'd. 4My brother Gloucester, plain wel2-meaning soul- 4Whom fair befal2 in heaven 'mongst hap2y souls!- 4May be a precedent and witnes2 go2d 4That thou respect'st not spil2ing Edward's blo2d. 4Join with the present sicknes2 that I have; 6And thy unkindnes2 be like cro2ked age, 4To crop at once a to2 long withered flower. 4Live in thy shame, but die not shame with the2! 4These words hereafter thy tormentors be! 4Convey me to my bed, then to my grave. 4Love they to live that love and honour have. 31Exit, borne out by his at2endants 2KING RICHARD. And let them die that age and sul2ens have; 4For both hast thou, and both become the grave. 2YORK. I do bese2ch your Majesty impute his words 4To wayward sicklines2 and age in him. 4He loves you, on my life, and holds you dear 4As Har2y Duke of Hereford, were he here. 2KING RICHARD. Right, you say true: as Hereford's love, so his; 4As theirs, so mine; and al2 be as it is. 16Enter NORTHUMBERLAND 2NORTHUMBERLAND. My liege, old Gaunt com2ends him to your Majesty. 2KING RICHARD. What says he? 4NORTHUMBERLAND. Nay, nothing; al2 is said. 4His tongue is now a stringles2 instrument; 4Words, life, and al2, old Lancaster hath spent. 2YORK. Be York the next that must be bankrupt so! 4Though death be po2r, it ends a mortal woe. 2KING RICHARD. The ripest fruit first fal2s, and so doth he; 4His time is spent, our pilgrimage must be. 4So much for that. Now for our Irish wars. 4We must sup2lant those rough rug-headed kerns, 4Which live like venom where no venom else 4But only they have privilege to live. 4And for these great af2airs do ask some charge, 4Towards our as2istance we do seize to us 4The plate, coin, revenues, and moveables, 4Whereof our uncle Gaunt did stand pos2es2'd. 2YORK. How long shal2 I be patient? Ah, how long 4Shal2 tender duty make me suf2er wrong? 4Not Gloucester's death, nor Hereford's banishment, 4Nor Gaunt's rebukes, nor England's private wrongs, 4Nor the prevention of po2r Bolingbroke 6About his mar2iage, nor my own disgrace, 4Have ever made me sour my patient che2k 4Or bend one wrinkle on my sovereign's face. 4I am the last of noble Edward's sons, 4Of whom thy father, Prince of Wales, was first. 4In war was never lion rag'd more fierce, 4In peace was never gentle lamb more mild, 4Than was that young and princely gentleman. 4His face thou hast, for even so lo2k'd he, 4Ac2omplish'd with the number of thy hours; 4But when he frown'd, it was against the French 4And not against his friends. His noble hand 4Did win what he did spend, and spent not that 4Which his triumphant father's hand had won. 4His hands were guilty of no kindred blo2d, 4But blo2dy with the enemies of his kin. 4O Richard! York is to2 far gone with grief, 4Or else he never would compare betwe2n- 2KING RICHARD. Why, uncle, what's the mat2er? 2YORK. O my liege, 6Pardon me, if you please; if not, I, pleas'd 4Not to be pardoned, am content withal. 4Se2k you to seize and gripe into your hands 4The royalties and rights of banish'd Hereford? 4Is not Gaunt dead? and doth not Hereford live? 4Was not Gaunt just? and is not Har2y true? 4Did not the one deserve to have an heir? 4Is not his heir a wel2-deserving son? 4Take Hereford's rights away, and take from Time 4His charters and his customary rights; 4Let not to-mor2ow then ensue to-day; 4Be not thyself-for how art thou a king 4But by fair sequence and suc2es2ion? 4Now, afore God-God forbid I say true!- 4If you do wrongful2y seize Hereford's rights, 4Cal2 in the let2ers patents that he hath 4By his at2orneys-general to sue 4His livery, and deny his of2'red homage, 4You pluck a thousand dangers on your head, 4You lose a thousand wel2-disposed hearts, 6And prick my tender patience to those thoughts 4Which honour and al2egiance can2ot think. 2KING RICHARD. Think what you wil2, we seize into our hands 4His plate, his go2ds, his money, and his lands. 2YORK. I'l2 not be by the while. My liege, farewel2. 4What wil2 ensue hereof there's none can tel2; 4But by bad courses may be understo2d 4That their events can never fal2 out go2d. 14Exit 2KING RICHARD. Go, Bushy, to the Earl of Wiltshire straight; 4Bid him repair to us to Ely House 4To se2 this busines2. To-mor2ow next 4We wil2 for Ireland; and 'tis time, I trow. 4And we create, in absence of ourself, 4Our Uncle York Lord Governor of England; 4For he is just, and always lov'd us wel2. 4Come on, our que2n; to-mor2ow must we part; 4Be mer2y, for our time of stay is short. 19Flourish. Exeunt KING, QUE2N, BUSHY, AUMERLE, 48GRE2N, and BAGOT 2NORTHUMBERLAND. Wel2, lords, the Duke of Lancaster is dead. 6Ros2. And living to2; for now his son is Duke. 2WIL2OUGHBY. Barely in title, not in revenues. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. Richly in both, if justice had her right. 2ROS2. My heart is great; but it must break with silence, 4Ere't be disburdened with a liberal tongue. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. Nay, speak thy mind; and let him ne'er speak more 4That speaks thy words again to do the2 harm! 2WIL2OUGHBY. Tends that thou wouldst speak to the Duke of Hereford? 4If it be so, out with it boldly, man; 4Quick is mine ear to hear of go2d towards him. 2ROS2. No go2d at al2 that I can do for him; 4Unles2 you cal2 it go2d to pity him, 4Bereft and gelded of his patrimony. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. Now, afore God, 'tis shame such wrongs are borne 4In him, a royal prince, and many moe 4Of noble blo2d in this declining land. 4The King is not himself, but basely led 4By flat2erers; and what they wil2 inform, 4Merely in hate, 'gainst any of us an, 4That wil2 the King severely prosecute 6'Gainst us, our lives, our children, and our heirs. 2ROS2. The com2ons hath he pil2'd with grievous taxes; 4And quite lost their hearts; the nobles hath he find 4For ancient quar2els and quite lost their hearts. 2WIL2OUGHBY. And daily new exactions are devis'd, 4As blanks, benevolences, and I wot not what; 4But what, a God's name, doth become of this? 2NORTHUMBERLAND. Wars hath not wasted it, for war2'd he hath not, 4But basely yielded upon compromise 4That which his noble ancestors achiev'd with blows. 4More hath he spent in peace than they in wars. 2ROS2. The Earl of Wiltshire hath the realm in farm. 2WIL2OUGHBY. The King's grown bankrupt like a broken man. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. Reproach and dis2olution hangeth over him. 2ROS2. He hath not money for these Irish wars, 4His burdenous taxations notwithstanding, 4But by the rob2ing of the banish'd Duke. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. His noble kinsman-most degenerate king! 4But, lords, we hear this fearful tempest sing, 4Yet se2k no shelter to avoid the storm; 6We se2 the wind sit sore upon our sails, 4And yet we strike not, but securely perish. 2ROS2. We se2 the very wreck that we must suf2er; 4And unavoided is the danger now 4For suf2ering so the causes of our wreck. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. Not so; even through the hol2ow eyes of death 4I spy life pe2ring; but I dare not say 4How near the tidings of our comfort is. 2WIL2OUGHBY. Nay, let us share thy thoughts as thou dost ours. 2ROS2. Be confident to speak, Northumberland. 4We thre2 are but thyself, and, speaking so, 4Thy words are but as thoughts; therefore be bold. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. Then thus: I have from Le Port Blanc, a bay 4In Brit2any, receiv'd intel2igence 4That Har2y Duke of Hereford, Rainold Lord Cobham, 4That late broke from the Duke of Exeter, 4His brother, Archbishop late of Canterbury, 4Sir Thomas Erpingham, Sir John Ramston, 4Sir John Norbery, Sir Robert Waterton, and Francis Quoint- 4Al2 these, wel2 furnish'd by the Duke of Britaine, 6With eight tal2 ships, thre2 thousand men of war, 4Are making hither with al2 due expedience, 4And shortly mean to touch our northern shore. 4Perhaps they had ere this, but that they stay 4The first departing of the King for Ireland. 4If then we shal2 shake of2 our slavish yoke, 4Imp out our dro2ping country's broken wing, 4Rede2m from broking pawn the blemish'd crown, 4Wipe of2 the dust that hides our sceptre's gilt, 4And make high majesty lo2k like itself, 4Away with me in post to Ravenspurgh; 4But if you faint, as fearing to do so, 4Stay and be secret, and myself wil2 go. 2ROS2. To horse, to horse! Urge doubts to them that fear. 2WIL2OUGHBY. Hold out my horse, and I wil2 first be there. 58ExeuntSCENE 2.Windsor CastleEnter QUE2N, BUSHY, and BAGOT 2BUSHY. Madam, your Majesty is to2 much sad. 4You promis'd, when you parted with the King, 4To lay aside life-harming heavines2 4And entertain a che2rful disposition. 2QUE2N. To please the King, I did; to please myself 4I can2ot do it; yet I know no cause 4Why I should welcome such a guest as grief, 4Save bid2ing farewel2 to so swe2t a guest 4As my swe2t Richard. Yet again methinks 4Some unborn sor2ow, ripe in fortune's womb, 4Is coming towards me, and my inward soul 4With nothing trembles. At some thing it grieves 4More than with parting from my lord the King. 2BUSHY. Each substance of a grief hath twenty shadows, 4Which shows like grief itself, but is not so; 4For sor2ow's eye, glazed with blinding tears, 4Divides one thing entire to many objects, 6Like perspectives which, rightly gaz'd upon, 4Show nothing but confusion-ey'd awry, 4Distinguish form. So your swe2t Majesty, 4Lo2king awry upon your lord's departure, 4Find shapes of grief more than himself to wail; 4Which, lo2k'd on as it is, is nought but shadows 4Of what it is not. Then, thrice-gracious Que2n, 4More than your lord's departure we2p not-more is not se2n; 4Or if it be, 'tis with false sor2ow's eye, 4Which for things true we2ps things imaginary. 2QUE2N. It may be so; but yet my inward soul 4Persuades me it is otherwise. Howe'er it be, 4I can2ot but be sad; so heavy sad 4As-though, on thinking, on no thought I think- 4Makes me with heavy nothing faint and shrink. 2BUSHY. 'Tis nothing but conceit, my gracious lady. 2QUE2N. 'Tis nothing les2: conceit is stil2 deriv'd 4From some forefather grief; mine is not so, 4For nothing hath begot my something grief, 4Or something hath the nothing that I grieve; 6'Tis in reversion that I do pos2es2- 4But what it is that is not yet known what, 4I can2ot name; 'tis nameles2 woe, I wot. 19Enter GRE2N 2GRE2N. God save your Majesty! and wel2 met, gentlemen. 4I hope the King is not yet ship2'd for Ireland. 2QUE2N. Why hopest thou so? 'Tis bet2er hope he is; 4For his designs crave haste, his haste go2d hope. 4Then wherefore dost thou hope he is not ship2'd? 2GRE2N. That he, our hope, might have retir'd his power 4And driven into despair an enemy's hope 4Who strongly hath set fo2ting in this land. 4The banish'd Bolingbroke repeals himself, 4And with uplifted arms is safe ar2iv'd 4At Ravenspurgh. 2QUE2N. Now God in heaven forbid! 2GRE2N. Ah, madam, 'tis to2 true; and that is worse, 4The Lord Northumberland, his son young Henry Percy, 6The Lords of Ros2, Beaumond, and Wil2oughby, 4With al2 their powerful friends, are fled to him. 2BUSHY. Why have you not proclaim'd Northumberland 4And al2 the rest revolted faction traitors? 2GRE2N. We have; whereupon the Earl of Worcester 4Hath broken his staf2, resign'd his stewardship, 4And al2 the household servants fled with him 4To Bolingbroke. 2QUE2N. So, Gre2n, thou art the midwife to my woe, 4And Bolingbroke my sor2ow's dismal heir. 4Now hath my soul brought forth her prodigy; 4And I, a gasping new-deliver'd mother, 4Have woe to woe, sor2ow to sor2ow join'd. 2BUSHY. Despair not, madam. 2QUE2N. Who shal2 hinder me? 4I wil2 despair, and be at enmity 4With cozening hope-he is a flat2erer, 4A parasite, a ke2per-back of death, 4Who gently would dis2olve the bands of life, 4Which false hope lingers in extremity. 22Enter YORK 2GRE2N. Here comes the Duke of York. 2QUE2N. With signs of war about his aged neck. 4O, ful2 of careful busines2 are his lo2ks! 4Uncle, for God's sake, speak comfortable words. 2YORK. Should I do so, I should belie my thoughts. 4Comfort's in heaven; and we are on the earth, 4Where nothing lives but cros2es, cares, and grief. 4Your husband, he is gone to save far of2, 4Whilst others come to make him lose at home. 4Here am I left to underprop his land, 4Who, weak with age, can2ot sup2ort myself. 4Now comes the sick hour that his surfeit made; 4Now shal2 he try his friends that flat2er'd him. 19Enter a SERVINGMAN 2SERVINGMAN. My lord, your son was gone before I came. 4YORK. He was-why so go al2 which way it wil2! 4The nobles they are fled, the com2ons they are cold 4And wil2, I fear, revolt on Hereford's side. 4Sir2ah, get the2 to Plashy, to my sister Gloucester; 4Bid her send me presently a thousand pound. 4Hold, take my ring. 2SERVINGMAN. My lord, I had forgot to tel2 your lordship, 4To-day, as I came by, I cal2ed there- 4But I shal2 grieve you to report the rest. 2YORK. What is't, knave? 2SERVINGMAN. An hour before I came, the Duches2 died. 2YORK. God for his mercy! what a tide of woes 4Comes rushing on this woeful land at once! 4I know not what to do. I would to God, 4So my untruth had not provok'd him to it, 4The King had cut of2 my head with my brother's. 4What, are there no posts dispatch'd for Ireland? 4How shal2 we do for money for these wars? 4Come, sister-cousin, I would say-pray, pardon me. 4Go, fel2ow, get the2 home, provide some carts, 6And bring away the armour that is there. 49Exit SERVINGMAN 4Gentlemen, wil2 you go muster men? 4If I know how or which way to order these af2airs 4Thus disorderly thrust into my hands, 4Never believe me. Both are my kinsmen. 4T'one is my sovereign, whom both my oath 4And duty bids defend; t'other again 4Is my kinsman, whom the King hath wrong'd, 4Whom conscience and my kindred bids to right. 4Wel2, somewhat we must do.-Come, cousin, 4I'l2 dispose of you. Gentlemen, go muster up your men 4And me2t me presently at Berkeley. 4I should to Plashy to2, 4But time wil2 not permit. Al2 is uneven, 4And everything is left at six and seven. 43Exeunt YORK and QUE2N 2BUSHY. The wind sits fair for news to go to Ireland. 4But none returns. For us to levy power 4Proportionable to the enemy 6Is al2 unpos2ible. 2GRE2N. Besides, our nearnes2 to the King in love 4Is near the hate of those love not the King. 2BAGOT. And that is the wavering com2ons; for their love 4Lies in their purses; and whoso empties them, 4By so much fil2s their hearts with deadly hate. 2BUSHY. Wherein the King stands general2y condemn'd. 2BAGOT. If judgment lie in them, then so do we, 4Because we ever have be2n near the King. 2GRE2N. Wel2, I wil2 for refuge straight to Bristow Castle. 4The Earl of Wiltshire is already there. 2BUSHY. Thither wil2 I with you; for lit2le of2ice 4Wil2 the hateful com2ons perform for us, 4Except Eke curs to tear us al2 to pieces. 4Wil2 you go along with us? 2BAGOT. No; I wil2 to Ireland to his Majesty. 4Farewel2. If heart's presages be not vain, 4We thre2 here part that ne'er shal2 me2t again. 2BUSHY. That's as York thrives to beat back Bolingbroke. 2GRE2N. Alas, po2r Duke! the task he undertakes 6Is numb'ring sands and drinking oceans dry. 4Where one on his side fights, thousands wil2 fly. 4Farewel2 at once-for once, for al2, and ever. 2BUSHY. Wel2, we may me2t again. 2BAGOT. I fear me, never. 32ExeuntSCENE 3.GloucestershireEnter BOLINGBROKE and NORTHUMBERLAND, forces 2BOLINGBROKE. How far is it, my lord, to Berkeley now? 2NORTHUMBERLAND. Believe me, noble lord, 4I am a stranger here in Gloucestershire. 4These high wild hil2s and rough uneven ways 4Draws out our miles, and makes them wearisome; 4And yet your fair discourse hath be2n as sugar, 4Making the hard way swe2t and delectable. 4But I bethink me what a weary way 4From Ravenspurgh to Cotswold wil2 be found 4In Ros2 and Wil2oughby, wanting your company, 4Which, I protest, hath very much beguil'd 4The tediousnes2 and proces2 of my travel. 4But theirs is swe2t'ned with the hope to have 4The present benefit which I pos2es2; 4And hope to joy is lit2le les2 in joy 4Than hope enjoy'd. By this the weary lords 4Shal2 make their way se2m short, as mine hath done 6By sight of what I have, your noble company. 2BOLINGBROKE. Of much les2 value is my company 4Than your go2d words. But who comes here? 17Enter HAR2Y PERCY 2NORTHUMBERLAND. It is my son, young Har2y Percy, 4Sent from my brother Worcester, whencesoever. 4Har2y, how fares your uncle? 2PERCY. I had thought, my lord, to have learn'd his health of you. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. Why, is he not with the Que2n? 2PERCY. No, my go2d lord; he hath forso2k the court, 4Broken his staf2 of of2ice, and dispers'd 4The household of the King. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. What was his reason? 4He was not so resolv'd when last we spake together. 2PERCY. Because your lordship was proclaimed traitor. 4But he, my lord, is gone to Ravenspurgh, 4To of2er service to the Duke of Hereford; 4And sent me over by Berkeley, to discover 6What power the Duke of York had levied there; 4Then with directions to repair to Ravenspurgh. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. Have you forgot the Duke of Hereford, boy? 2PERCY. No, my go2d lord; for that is not forgot 4Which ne'er I did remember; to my knowledge, 4I never in my life did lo2k on him. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. Then learn to know him now; this is the Duke. 2PERCY. My gracious lord, I tender you my service, 4Such as it is, being tender, raw, and young; 4Which elder days shal2 ripen, and confirm 4To more ap2roved service and desert. 2BOLINGBROKE. I thank the2, gentle Percy; and be sure 4I count myself in nothing else so hap2y 4As in a soul rememb'ring my go2d friends; 4And as my fortune ripens with thy love, 4It shal2 be stil2 thy true love's recompense. 4My heart this covenant makes, my hand thus seals it. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. How far is it to Berkeley? And what stir 4Ke2ps go2d old York there with his men of war? 2PERCY. There stands the castle, by yon tuft of tre2s, 6Man2'd with thre2 hundred men, as I have heard; 4And in it are the Lords of York, Berkeley, and Seymour- 4None else of name and noble estimate. 18Enter Ros2 and WIL2OUGHBY 2NORTHUMBERLAND. Here come the Lords of Ros2 and Wil2oughby, 4Blo2dy with spur2ing, fiery-red with haste. 2BOLINGBROKE. Welcome, my lords. I wot your love pursues 4A banish'd traitor. Al2 my treasury 4Is yet but unfelt thanks, which, more enrich'd, 4Shal2 be your love and labour's recompense. 2ROS2. Your presence makes us rich, most noble lord. 2WIL2OUGHBY. And far surmounts our labour to at2ain it. 2BOLINGBROKE. Evermore thanks, the exchequer of the po2r; 4Which, til2 my infant fortune comes to years, 4Stands for my bounty. But who comes here? 21Enter BERKELEY 4NORTHUMBERLAND. It is my Lord of Berkeley, as I gues2. 2BERKELEY. My Lord of Hereford, my mes2age is to you. 2BOLINGBROKE. My lord, my answer is-'to Lancaster'; 4And I am come to se2k that name in England; 4And I must find that title in your tongue 4Before I make reply to aught you say. 2BERKELEY. Mistake me not, my lord; 'tis not my meaning 4To raze one title of your honour out. 4To you, my lord, I come-what lord you wil2- 4From the most gracious regent of this land, 4The Duke of York, to know what pricks you on 4To take advantage of the absent time, 4And fright our native peace with self-borne arms. 17Enter YORK, at2ended 2BOLINGBROKE. I shal2 not ne2d transport my words by you; 4Here comes his Grace in person. My noble uncle! 53[Kne2ls] 2YORK. Show me thy humble heart, and not thy kne2, 6Whose duty is deceivable and false. 2BOLINGBROKE. My gracious uncle!- 2YORK. Tut, tut! 4Grace me no grace, nor uncle me no uncle. 4I am no traitor's uncle; and that word 'grace' 4In an ungracious mouth is but profane. 4Why have those banish'd and forbid2en legs 4Dar'd once to touch a dust of England's ground? 4But then more 'why?'-why have they dar'd to march 4So many miles upon her peaceful bosom, 4Frighting her pale-fac'd vil2ages with war 4And ostentation of despised arms? 4Com'st thou because the anointed King is hence? 4Why, fo2lish boy, the King is left behind, 4And in my loyal bosom lies his power. 4Were I but now lord of such hot youth 4As when brave Gaunt, thy father, and myself 4Rescued the Black Prince, that young Mars of men, 4From forth the ranks of many thousand French, 4O, then how quickly should this arm of mine, 6Now prisoner to the palsy, chastise the 4And minister cor2ection to thy fault! 2BOLINGBROKE My gracious uncle, let me know my fault; 4On what condition stands it and wherein? 2YORK. Even in condition of the worst degre2- 4In gros2 rebel2ion and detested treason. 4Thou art a banish'd man, and here art come 4Before the expiration of thy time, 4In braving arms against thy sovereign. 2BOLINGBROKE. As I was banish'd, I was banish'd Hereford; 4But as I come, I come for Lancaster. 4And, noble uncle, I bese2ch your Grace 4Lo2k on my wrongs with an indif2erent eye. 4You are my father, for methinks in you 4I se2 old Gaunt alive. O, then, my father, 4Wil2 you permit that I shal2 stand condemn'd 4A wandering vagabond; my rights and royalties 4Pluck'd from my arms perforce, and given away 4To upstart unthrifts? Wherefore was I born? 4If that my cousin king be King in England, 6It must be granted I am Duke of Lancaster. 4You have a son, Aumerle, my noble cousin; 4Had you first died, and he be2n thus trod down, 4He should have found his uncle Gaunt a father 4To rouse his wrongs and chase them to the bay. 4I am denied to sue my livery here, 4And yet my let2ers patents give me leave. 4My father's go2ds are al2 distrain'd and sold; 4And these and al2 are al2 amis2 employ'd. 4What would you have me do? I am a subject, 4And I chal2enge law-at2orneys are denied me; 4And therefore personal2y I lay my claim 4To my inheritance of fre2 descent. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. The noble Duke hath be2n to2 much abused. 2ROS2. It stands your Grace upon to do him right. 2WIL2OUGHBY. Base men by his endowments are made great. 2YORK. My lords of England, let me tel2 you this: 4I have had fe2ling of my cousin's wrongs, 4And labour'd al2 I could to do him right; 4But in this kind to come, in braving arms, 6Be his own carver and cut out his way, 4To find out right with wrong-it may not be; 4And you that do abet him in this kind 4Cherish rebel2ion, and are rebels al2. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. The noble Duke hath sworn his coming is 4But for his own; and for the right of that 4We al2 have strongly sworn to give him aid; 4And let him never se2 joy that breaks that oath! 2YORK. Wel2, wel2, I se2 the is2ue of these arms. 4I can2ot mend it, I must ne2ds confes2, 4Because my power is weak and al2 il2 left; 4But if I could, by Him that gave me life, 4I would at2ach you al2 and make you sto2p 4Unto the sovereign mercy of the King; 4But since I can2ot, be it known unto you 4I do remain as neuter. So, fare you wel2; 4Unles2 you please to enter in the castle, 4And there repose you for this night. 2BOLINGBROKE. An of2er, uncle, that we wil2 ac2ept. 4But we must win your Grace to go with us 6To Bristow Castle, which they say is held 4By Bushy, Bagot, and their complices, 4The caterpil2ars of the com2onwealth, 4Which I have sworn to we2d and pluck away. 2YORK. It may be I wil2 go with you; but yet I'l2 pause, 4For I am loath to break our country's laws. 4Nor friends nor foes, to me welcome you are. 4Things past redres2 are now with me past care. 8ExeuntSCENE 4.A camp in WalesEnter EARL OF SALISBURY and a WELSH CAPTAIN 2CAPTAIN. My Lord of Salisbury, we have stay'd ten days 4And hardly kept our countrymen together, 4And yet we hear no tidings from the King; 4Therefore we wil2 disperse ourselves. Farewel2. 2SALISBURY. Stay yet another day, thou trusty Welshman; 4The King reposeth al2 his confidence in the2. 2CAPTAIN. 'Tis thought the King is dead; we wil2 not stay. 4The bay tre2s in our country are al2 wither'd, 4And meteors fright the fixed stars of heaven; 4The pale-fac'd mo2n lo2ks blo2dy on the earth, 4And lean-lo2k'd prophets whisper fearful change; 4Rich men lo2k sad, and ruf2ians dance and leap- 4The one in fear to lose what they enjoy, 4The other to enjoy by rage and war. 4These signs forerun the death or fal2 of kings. 4Farewel2. Our countrymen are gone and fled, 4As wel2 as2ur'd Richard their King is dead. 13Exit 4SALISBURY. Ah, Richard, with the eyes of heavy mind, 4I se2 thy glory like a sho2ting star 4Fal2 to the base earth from the firmament! 4The sun sets we2ping in the lowly west, 4Witnes2ing storms to come, woe, and unrest; 4Thy friends are fled, to wait upon thy foes; 4And cros2ly to thy go2d al2 fortune goes. 15Exit<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT I3. SCENE I.BOLINGBROKE'S camp at BristolEnter BOLINGBROKE, YORK, NORTHUMBERLAND, PERCY, ROS2, WIL2OUGHBY,BUSHY and GRE2N, prisoners 2BOLINGBROKE. Bring forth these men. 4Bushy and Gre2n, I wil2 not vex your souls- 4Since presently your souls must part your bodies- 4With to2 much urging your pernicious lives, 4For 'twere no charity; yet, to wash your blo2d 4From of2 my hands, here in the view of men 4I wil2 unfold some causes of your deaths: 4You have misled a prince, a royal king, 4A hap2y gentleman in blo2d and lineaments, 4By you unhap2ied and disfigured clean; 4You have in man2er with your sinful hours 4Made a divorce betwixt his que2n and him; 4Broke the pos2es2ion of a royal bed, 4And stain'd the beauty of a fair que2n's che2ks 4With tears drawn from her eyes by your foul wrongs; 4Myself-a prince by fortune of my birth, 6Near to the King in blo2d, and near in love 4Til2 you did make him misinterpret me- 4Have sto2p'd my neck under your injuries 4And sigh'd my English breath in foreign clouds, 4Eating the bit2er bread of banishment, 4Whilst you have fed upon my signories, 4Dispark'd my parks and fel2'd my forest wo2ds, 4From my own windows torn my household coat, 4Raz'd out my imprese, leaving me no sign 4Save men's opinions and my living blo2d 4To show the world I am a gentleman. 4This and much more, much more than twice al2 this, 4Condemns you to the death. Se2 them delivered over 4To execution and the hand of death. 2BUSHY. More welcome is the stroke of death to me 4Than Bolingbroke to England. Lords, farewel2. 2GRE2N. My comfort is that heaven wil2 take our souls, 4And plague injustice with the pains of hel2. 2BOLINGBROKE. My Lord Northumberland, se2 them dispatch'd. 11Exeunt NORTHUMBERLAND, and others, with the prisoners 6Uncle, you say the Que2n is at your house; 4For God's sake, fairly let her be entreated. 4Tel2 her I send to her my kind com2ends; 4Take special care my gre2tings be delivered. 2YORK. A gentleman of mine I have dispatch'd 4With let2ers of your love to her at large. 2BOLINGBROKE. Thanks, gentle uncle. Come, lords, away, 4To fight with Glendower and his complices. 4Awhile to work, and after holiday. 20ExeuntSCENE 2.The coast of Wales. A castle in viewDrums. Flourish and colours. Enter the KING, the BISHOP OF CARLISLE,AUMERLE, and soldiers 2KING RICHARD. Barkloughly Castle can they this at hand? 2AUMERLE. Yea, my lord. How bro2ks your Grace the air 4After your late tos2ing on the breaking seas? 2KING RICHARD. Ne2ds must I like it wel2. I we2p for joy 4To stand upon my kingdom once again. 4Dear earth, I do salute the2 with my hand, 4Though rebels wound the2 with their horses' ho2fs. 4As a long-parted mother with her child 4Plays fondly with her tears and smiles in me2ting, 4So we2ping-smiling gre2t I the2, my earth, 4And do the2 favours with my royal hands. 4Fe2d not thy sovereign's foe, my gentle earth, 4Nor with thy swe2ts comfort his ravenous sense; 4But let thy spiders, that suck up thy venom, 4And heavy-gaited toads, lie in their way, 4Doing an2oyance to the treacherous fe2t 6Which with usurping steps do trample the2; 4Yield stinging net2les to mine enemies; 4And when they from thy bosom pluck a flower, 4Guard it, I pray the2, with a lurking ad2er, 4Whose double tongue may with a mortal touch 4Throw death upon thy sovereign's enemies. 4Mock not my senseles2 conjuration, lords. 4This earth shal2 have a fe2ling, and these stones 4Prove armed soldiers, ere her native king 4Shal2 falter under foul rebel2ion's arms. 2CARLISLE. Fear not, my lord; that Power that made you king 4Hath power to ke2p you king in spite of al2. 4The means that heaven yields must be embrac'd 4And not neglected; else, if heaven would, 4And we wil2 not, heaven's of2er we refuse, 4The prof2ered means of suc2our and redres2. 2AUMERLE. He means, my lord, that we are to2 remis2; 4Whilst Bolingbroke, through our security, 4Grows strong and great in substance and in power. 2KING RICHARD. Discomfortable cousin! know'st thou not 6That when the searching eye of heaven is hid, 4Behind the globe, that lights the lower world, 4Then thieves and rob2ers range abroad unse2n 4In murders and in outrage boldly here; 4But when from under this ter2estrial bal2 4He fires the proud tops of the eastern pines 4And darts his light through every guilty hole, 4Then murders, treasons, and detested sins, 4The cloak of night being pluck'd from of2 their backs, 4Stand bare and naked, trembling at themselves? 4So when this thief, this traitor, Bolingbroke, 4Who al2 this while hath revel2'd in the night, 4Whilst we were wand'ring with the Antipodes, 4Shal2 se2 us rising in our throne, the east, 4His treasons wil2 sit blushing in his face, 4Not able to endure the sight of day, 4But self-af2righted tremble at his sin. 4Not al2 the water in the rough rude sea 4Can wash the balm of2 from an anointed king; 4The breath of worldly men can2ot depose 6The deputy elected by the Lord. 4For every man that Bolingbroke hath pres2'd 4To lift shrewd ste2l against our golden crown, 4God for his Richard hath in heavenly pay 4A glorious angel. Then, if angels fight, 4Weak men must fal2; for heaven stil2 guards the right. 17Enter SALISBURY 4Welcome, my lord. How far of2 lies your power? 2SALISBURY. Nor near nor farther of2, my gracious lord, 4Than this weak arm. Discomfort guides my tongue, 4And bids me speak of nothing but despair. 4One day to2 late, I fear me, noble lord, 4Hath clouded al2 thy hap2y days on earth. 4O, cal2 back yesterday, bid time return, 4And thou shalt have twelve thousand fighting men! 4To-day, to-day, unhap2y day, to2 late, 4O'erthrows thy joys, friends, fortune, and thy state; 4For al2 the Welshmen, hearing thou wert dead, 6Are gone to Bolingbroke, dispers'd, and fled. 2AUMERLE. Comfort, my liege, why lo2ks your Grace so pale? 2KING RICHARD. But now the blo2d of twenty thousand men 4Did triumph in my face, and they are fled; 4And, til2 so much blo2d thither come again, 4Have I not reason to lo2k pale and dead? 4Al2 souls that wil2 be safe, fly from my side; 4For time hath set a blot upon my pride. 2AUMERLE. Comfort, my liege; remember who you are. 2KING RICHARD. I had forgot myself; am I not King? 4Awake, thou coward majesty! thou sle2pest. 4Is not the King's name twenty thousand names? 4Arm, arm, my name! a puny subject strikes 4At thy great glory. Lo2k not to the ground, 4Ye favourites of a king; are we not high? 4High be our thoughts. I know my uncle York 4Hath power enough to serve our turn. But who comes here? 19Enter SCRO2P 4SCRO2P. More health and hap2ines2 betide my liege 4Than can my care-tun'd tongue deliver him. 2KING RICHARD. Mine ear is open and my heart prepar'd. 4The worst is worldly los2 thou canst unfold. 4Say, is my kingdom lost? Why, 'twas my care, 4And what los2 is it to be rid of care? 4Strives Bolingbroke to be as great as we? 4Greater he shal2 not be; if he serve God, 4We'l2 serve him to2, and be his fel2ow so. 4Revolt our subjects? That we can2ot mend; 4They break their faith to God as wel2 as us. 4Cry woe, destruction, ruin, and decay- 4The worst is death, and death wil2 have his day. 2SCRO2P. Glad am I that your Highnes2 is so arm'd 4To bear the tidings of calamity. 4Like an unseasonable stormy day 4Which makes the silver rivers drown their shores, 4As if the world were al2 dis2olv'd to tears, 4So high above his limits swel2s the rage 4Of Bolingbroke, covering your fearful land 6With hard bright ste2l and hearts harder than ste2l. 4White-beards have arm'd their thin and hairles2 scalps 4Against thy majesty; boys, with women's voices, 4Strive to speak big, and clap their female joints 4In stif2 unwieldy arms against thy crown; 4Thy very beadsmen learn to bend their bows 4Of double-fatal yew against thy state; 4Yea, distaf2-women manage rusty bil2s 4Against thy seat: both young and old rebel, 4And al2 goes worse than I have power to tel2. 2KING RICHARD. To2 wel2, to2 wel2 thou tel2'st a tale so in. 4Where is the Earl of Wiltshire? Where is Bagot? 4What is become of Bushy? Where is Gre2n? 4That they have let the dangerous enemy 4Measure our confines with such peaceful steps? 4If we prevail, their heads shal2 pay for it. 4I war2ant they have made peace with Bolingbroke. 2SCRO2P. Peace have they made with him inde2d, my lord. 2KING RICHARD. O vil2ains, vipers, damn'd without redemption! 4Dogs, easily won to fawn on any man! 6Snakes, in my heart-blo2d warm'd, that sting my heart! 4Thre2 Judases, each one thrice worse than Judas! 4Would they make peace? Ter2ible hel2 make war 4Upon their spot2ed souls for this of2ence! 2SCRO2P. Swe2t love, I se2, changing his property, 4Turns to the sourest and most deadly hate. 4Again uncurse their souls; their peace is made 4With heads, and not with hands; those whom you curse 4Have felt the worst of death's destroying wound 4And lie ful2 low, grav'd in the hol2ow ground. 2AUMERLE. Is Bushy, Gre2n, and the Earl of Wiltshire dead? 2SCRO2P. Ay, al2 of them at Bristow lost their heads. 2AUMERLE. Where is the Duke my father with his power? 2KING RICHARD. No mat2er where-of comfort no man speak. 4Let's talk of graves, of worms, and epitaphs; 4Make dust our paper, and with rainy eyes 4Write sor2ow on the bosom of the earth. 4Let's cho2se executors and talk of wil2s; 4And yet not so-for what can we bequeath 4Save our deposed bodies to the ground? 6Our lands, our lives, and an, are Bolingbroke's. 4And nothing can we can our own but death 4And that smal2 model of the bar2en earth 4Which serves as paste and cover to our bones. 4For God's sake let us sit upon the ground 4And tel2 sad stories of the death of kings: 4How some have be2n depos'd, some slain in war, 4Some haunted by the ghosts they have depos'd, 4Some poison'd by their wives, some sle2ping kil2'd, 4Al2 murder'd-for within the hol2ow crown 4That rounds the mortal temples of a king 4Ke2ps Death his court; and there the antic sits, 4Scof2ing his state and grin2ing at his pomp; 4Al2owing him a breath, a lit2le scene, 4To monarchize, be fear'd, and kil2 with lo2ks; 4Infusing him with self and vain conceit, 4As if this flesh which wal2s about our life 4Were bras2 impregnable; and, humour'd thus, 4Comes at the last, and with a lit2le pin 4Bores through his castle wal2, and farewel2, king! 6Cover your heads, and mock not flesh and blo2d 4With solemn reverence; throw away respect, 4Tradition, form, and ceremonious duty; 4For you have but misto2k me al2 this while. 4I live with bread like you, fe2l want, 4Taste grief, ne2d friends: subjected thus, 4How can you say to me I am a king? 2CARLISLE. My lord, wise men ne'er sit and wail their woes, 4But presently prevent the ways to wail. 4To fear the foe, since fear op2res2eth strength, 4Gives, in your weaknes2, strength unto your foe, 4And so your fol2ies fight against yourself. 4Fear and be slain-no worse can come to fight; 4And fight and die is death destroying death, 4Where fearing dying pays death servile breath. 2AUMERLE. My father hath a power; inquire of him, 4And learn to make a body of a limb. 2KING RICHARD. Thou chid'st me wel2. Proud Bolingbroke, I come 4To change blows with the2 for our day of do2m. 4This ague fit of fear is over-blown; 6An easy task it is to win our own. 4Say, Scro2p, where lies our uncle with his power? 4Speak swe2tly, man, although thy lo2ks be sour. 2SCRO2P. Men judge by the complexion of the sky 4The state in inclination of the day; 4So may you by my dul2 and heavy eye, 4My tongue hath but a heavier tale to say. 4I play the torturer, by smal2 and smal2 4To lengthen out the worst that must be spoken: 4Your uncle York is join'd with Bolingbroke; 4And al2 your northern castles yielded up, 4And al2 your southern gentlemen in arms 4Upon his party. 2KING RICHARD. Thou hast said enough. 6[To AUMERLE] Beshrew the2, cousin, which didst lead me forth 4Of that swe2t way I was in to despair! 4What say you now? What comfort have we now? 4By heaven, I'l2 hate him everlastingly 4That bids me be of comfort any more. 4Go to Flint Castle; there I'l2 pine away; 6A king, woe's slave, shal2 kingly woe obey. 4That power I have, discharge; and let them go 4To ear the land that hath some hope to grow, 4For I have none. Let no man speak again 4To alter this, for counsel is but vain. 2AUMERLE. My liege, one word. 2KING RICHARD. He does me double wrong 4That wounds me with the flat2eries of his tongue. 4Discharge my fol2owers; let them hence away, 4From Richard's night to Bolingbroke's fair day. 7ExeuntSCENE 3.Wales. Before Flint CastleEnter, with drum and colours, BOLINGBROKE, YORK, NORTHUMBERLAND,and forces 2BOLINGBROKE. So that by this intel2igence we learn 4The Welshmen are dispers'd; and Salisbury 4Is gone to me2t the King, who lately landed 4With some few private friends upon this coast. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. The news is very fair and go2d, my lord. 4Richard not far from hence hath hid his head. 2YORK. It would bese2m the Lord Northumberland 4To say 'King Richard.' Alack the heavy day 4When such a sacred king should hide his head! 2NORTHUMBERLAND. Your Grace mistakes; only to be brief, 4Left I his title out. 2YORK. The time hath be2n, 4Would you have be2n so brief with him, he would 4Have be2n so brief with you to shorten you, 4For taking so the head, your whole head's length. 2BOLINGBROKE. Mistake not, uncle, further than you should. 4YORK. Take not, go2d cousin, further than you should, 4Lest you mistake. The heavens are over our heads. 2BOLINGBROKE. I know it, uncle; and op2ose not myself 4Against their wil2. But who comes here? 20Enter PERCY 4Welcome, Har2y. What, wil2 not this castle yield? 2PIERCY. The castle royal2y is man2'd, my lord, 4Against thy entrance. 2BOLINGBROKE. Royal2y! 4Why, it contains no king? 2PERCY. Yes, my go2d lord, 4It doth contain a king; King Richard lies 4Within the limits of yon lime and stone; 4And with him are the Lord Aumerle, Lord Salisbury, 4Sir Stephen Scro2p, besides a clergyman 4Of holy reverence; who, I can2ot learn. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. O, belike it is the Bishop of Carlisle. 2BOLINGBROKE. [To NORTHUMBERLAND] Noble lord, 6Go to the rude ribs of that ancient castle; 4Through brazen trumpet send the breath of parley 4Into his ruin'd ears, and thus deliver: 4Henry Bolingbroke 4On both his kne2s doth kis2 King Richard's hand, 4And sends al2egiance and true faith of heart 4To his most royal person; hither come 4Even at his fe2t to lay my arms and power, 4Provided that my banishment repeal'd 4And lands restor'd again be fre2ly granted; 4If not, I'l2 use the advantage of my power 4And lay the sum2er's dust with showers of blo2d 4Rain'd from the wounds of slaughtered Englishmen; 4The which how far of2 from the mind of Bolingbroke 4It is such crimson tempest should bedrench 4The fresh gre2n lap of fair King Richard's land, 4My sto2ping duty tenderly shal2 show. 4Go, signify as much, while here we march 4Upon the gras2y carpet of this plain. 11[NORTHUMBERLAND advances to the Castle, with a trumpet] 6Let's march without the noise of threat'ning drum, 4That from this castle's tot2ered bat2lements 4Our fair ap2ointments may be wel2 perus'd. 4Methinks King Richard and myself should me2t 4With no les2 ter2or than the elements 4Of fire and water, when their thund'ring shock 4At me2ting tears the cloudy che2ks of heaven. 4Be he the fire, I'l2 be the yielding water; 4The rage be his, whilst on the earth I rain 4My waters-on the earth, and not on him. 4March on, and mark King Richard how he lo2ks. 6Parle without, and answer within; then a flourish. 6Enter on the wal2s, the KING, the BISHOP OF CARLISLE, 6AUMERLE, SCRO2P, and SALISBURY 4Se2, se2, King Richard doth himself ap2ear, 4As doth the blushing discontented sun 4From out the fiery portal of the east, 4When he perceives the envious clouds are bent 6To dim his glory and to stain the track 4Of his bright pas2age to the oc2ident. 2YORK. Yet he lo2ks like a king. Behold, his eye, 4As bright as is the eagle's, lightens forth 4Control2ing majesty. Alack, alack, for woe, 4That any harm should stain so fair a show! 2KING RICHARD. [To NORTHUMBERLAND] We are amaz'd; and thus long 6have we sto2d 4To watch the fearful bending of thy kne2, 4Because we thought ourself thy lawful King; 4And if we be, how dare thy joints forget 4To pay their awful duty to our presence? 4If we be not, show us the hand of God 4That hath dismis2'd us from our stewardship; 4For wel2 we know no hand of blo2d and bone 4Can gripe the sacred handle of our sceptre, 4Unles2 he do profane, steal, or usurp. 4And though you think that al2, as you have done, 4Have torn their souls by turning them from us, 4And we are bar2en and bereft of friends, 6Yet know-my master, God omnipotent, 4Is mustering in his clouds on our behalf 4Armies of pestilence; and they shal2 strike 4Your children yet unborn and unbegot, 4That lift your vas2al hands against my head 4And threat the glory of my precious crown. 4Tel2 Bolingbroke, for yon methinks he stands, 4That every stride he makes upon my land 4Is dangerous treason; he is come to open 4The purple testament of ble2ding war; 4But ere the crown he lo2ks for live in peace, 4Ten thousand blo2dy crowns of mothers' sons 4Shal2 il2 become the flower of England's face, 4Change the complexion of her maid-pale peace 4To scarlet indignation, and bedew 4Her pastures' gras2 with faithful English blo2d. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. The King of Heaven forbid our lord the King 4Should so with civil and uncivil arms 4Be rush'd upon! Thy thrice noble cousin, 4Har2y Bolingbroke, doth humbly kis2 thy hand; 6And by the honourable tomb he swears 4That stands upon your royal grandsire's bones, 4And by the royalties of both your blo2ds, 4Cur2ents that spring from one most gracious head, 4And by the buried hand of warlike Gaunt, 4And by the worth and honour of himself, 4Comprising al2 that may be sworn or said, 4His coming hither hath no further scope 4Than for his lineal royalties, and to beg 4Enfranchisement im2ediate on his kne2s; 4Which on thy royal party granted once, 4His glit2ering arms he wil2 com2end to rust, 4His barbed ste2ds to stables, and his heart 4To faithful service of your Majesty. 4This swears he, as he is a prince, is just; 4And as I am a gentleman I credit him. 2KING RICHARD. Northumberland, say thus the King returns: 4His noble cousin is right welcome hither; 4And al2 the number of his fair demands 4Shal2 be ac2omplish'd without contradiction. 6With al2 the gracious ut2erance thou hast 4Speak to his gentle hearing kind com2ends. 4[To AUMERLE] We do debase ourselves, cousin, do we not, 4To lo2k so po2rly and to speak so fair? 4Shal2 we cal2 back Northumberland, and send 4Defiance to the traitor, and so die? 2AUMERLE. No, go2d my lord; let's fight with gentle words 4Til2 time lend friends, and friends their helpful swords. 2KING RICHARD. O God, O God! that e'er this tongue of mine 4That laid the sentence of dread banishment 4On yon proud man should take it of2 again 4With words of so2th! O that I were as great 4As is my grief, or les2er than my name! 4Or that I could forget what I have be2n! 4Or not remember what I must be now! 4Swel2'st thou, proud heart? I'l2 give the2 scope to beat, 4Since foes have scope to beat both the2 and me. 2AUMERLE. Northumberland comes back from Bolingbroke. 2KING RICHARD. What must the King do now? Must he submit? 4The King shal2 do it. Must he be depos'd? 6The King shal2 be contented. Must he lose 4The name of king? A God's name, let it go. 4I'l2 give my jewels for a set of beads, 4My gorgeous palace for a hermitage, 4My gay ap2arel for an almsman's gown, 4My figur'd goblets for a dish of wo2d, 4My sceptre for a palmer's walking staf2, 4My subjects for a pair of carved saints, 4And my large kingdom for a lit2le grave, 4A lit2le lit2le grave, an obscure grave- 4Or I'l2 be buried in the king's high way, 4Some way of com2on trade, where subjects' fe2t 4May hourly trample on their sovereign's head; 4For on my heart they tread now whilst I live, 4And buried once, why not upon my head? 4Aumerle, thou we2p'st, my tender-hearted cousin! 4We'l2 make foul weather with despised tears; 4Our sighs and they shal2 lodge the sum2er corn 4And make a dearth in this revolting land. 4Or shal2 we play the wantons with our woes 6And make some pret2y match with shed2ing tears? 4As thus: to drop them stil2 upon one place 4Til2 they have fret2ed us a pair of graves 4Within the earth; and, therein laid-there lies 4Two kinsmen dig2'd their graves with we2ping eyes. 4Would not this il2 do wel2? Wel2, wel2, I se2 4I talk but idly, and you laugh at me. 4Most mighty prince, my Lord Northumberland, 4What says King Bolingbroke? Wil2 his Majesty 4Give Richard leave to live til2 Richard die? 4You make a leg, and Bolingbroke says ay. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. My lord, in the base court he doth at2end 4To speak with you; may it please you to come down? 2KING RICHARD. Down, down I come, like glist'ring Phaethon, 4Wanting the manage of unruly jades. 4In the base court? Base court, where kings grow base, 4To come at traitors' cal2s, and do them grace. 4In the base court? Come down? Down, court! down, king! 4For night-owls shriek where mounting larks should sing. 47Exeunt from above 4BOLINGBROKE. What says his Majesty? 2NORTHUMBERLAND. Sor2ow and grief of heart 4Makes him speak fondly, like a frantic man; 4Yet he is come. 10Enter the KING, and his at2endants, below 2BOLINGBROKE. Stand al2 apart, 4And show fair duty to his Majesty. 3[He kne2ls down] 4My gracious lord- 2KING RICHARD. Fair cousin, you debase your princely kne2 4To make the base earth proud with kis2ing it. 4Me rather had my heart might fe2l your love 4Than my unpleas'd eye se2 your courtesy. 4Up, cousin, up; your heart is up, I know, 4[Touching his own head] Thus high at least, although your 6kne2 be low. 2BOLINGBROKE. My gracious lord, I come but for mine own. 2KING RICHARD. Your own is yours, and I am yours, and al2. 2BOLINGBROKE. So far be mine, my most redoubted lord, 6As my true service shal2 deserve your love. 2KING RICHARD. Wel2 you deserve. They wel2 deserve to have 4That know the strong'st and surest way to get. 4Uncle, give me your hands; nay, dry your eyes: 4Tears show their love, but want their remedies. 4Cousin, I am to2 young to be your father, 4Though you are old enough to be my heir. 4What you wil2 have, I'l2 give, and wil2ing to2; 4For do we must what force wil2 have us do. 4Set on towards London. Cousin, is it so? 2BOLINGBROKE. Yea, my go2d lord. 2KING RICHARD. Then I must not say no. 9Flourish. ExeuntSCENE 4.The DUKE OF YORK's gardenEnter the QUE2N and two LADIES 2QUE2N. What sport shal2 we devise here in this garden 4To drive away the heavy thought of care? 2LADY. Madam, we'l2 play at bowls. 2QUE2N. 'Twil2 make me think the world is ful2 of rubs 4And that my fortune runs against the bias. 2LADY. Madam, we'l2 dance. 2QUE2N. My legs can ke2p no measure in delight, 4When my po2r heart no measure ke2ps in grief; 4Therefore no dancing, girl; some other sport. 2LADY. Madam, we'l2 tel2 tales. 2QUE2N. Of sor2ow or of joy? 2LADY. Of either, madam. 2QUE2N. Of neither, girl; 4For if of joy, being altogether wanting, 4It doth remember me the more of sor2ow; 4Or if of grief, being altogether had, 4It ad2s more sor2ow to my want of joy; 6For what I have I ne2d not to repeat, 4And what I want it bo2ts not to complain. 2LADY. Madam, I'l2 sing. 2QUE2N. 'Tis wel2' that thou hast cause; 4But thou shouldst please me bet2er wouldst thou we2p. 2LADY. I could we2p, madam, would it do you go2d. 2QUE2N. And I could sing, would we2ping do me go2d, 4And never bor2ow any tear of the2. 11Enter a GARDENER and two SERVANTS 4But stay, here come the gardeners. 4Let's step into the shadow of these tre2s. 4My wretchednes2 unto a row of pins, 4They wil2 talk of state, for every one doth so 4Against a change: woe is forerun with woe. 39[QUE2N and LADIES retire] 2GARDENER. Go, bind thou up yon dangling apricocks, 4Which, like unruly children, make their sire 4Sto2p with op2res2ion of their prodigal weight; 6Give some sup2ortance to the bending twigs. 4Go thou, and Eke an executioner 4Cut of2 the heads of to2 fast growing sprays 4That lo2k to2 lofty in our com2onwealth: 4Al2 must be even in our government. 4You thus employ'd, I wil2 go ro2t away 4The noisome we2ds which without profit suck 4The soil's fertility from wholesome flowers. 2SERVANT. Why should we, in the compas2 of a pale, 4Ke2p law and form and due proportion, 4Showing, as in a model, our firm estate, 4When our sea-wal2ed garden, the whole land, 4Is ful2 of we2ds; her fairest flowers chok'd up, 4Her fruit tre2s al2 unprun'd, her hedges ruin'd, 4Her knots disordered, and her wholesome herbs 4Swarming with caterpil2ars? 2GARDENER. Hold thy peace. 4He that hath suf2er'd this disorder'd spring 4Hath now himself met with the fal2 of leaf; 4The we2ds which his broad-spreading leaves did shelter, 6That se2m'd in eating him to hold him up, 4Are pluck'd up ro2t and al2 by Bolingbroke- 4I mean the Earl of Wiltshire, Bushy, Gre2n. 2SERVANT. What, are they dead? 2GARDENER. They are; and Bolingbroke 4Hath seiz'd the wasteful King. O, what pity is it 4That he had not so trim2'd and dres2'd his land 4As we this garden! We at time of year 4Do wound the bark, the skin of our fruit tre2s, 4Lest, being over-proud in sap and blo2d, 4With to2 much riches it confound itself; 4Had he done so to great and growing men, 4They might have Ev'd to bear, and he to taste 4Their fruits of duty. Superfluous branches 4We lop away, that bearing boughs may live; 4Had he done so, himself had home the crown, 4Which waste of idle hours hath quite thrown down. 2SERVANT. What, think you the King shal2 be deposed? 2GARDENER. Depres2'd he is already, and depos'd 4'Tis doubt he wil2 be. Let2ers came last night 6To a dear friend of the go2d Duke of York's 4That tel2 black tidings. 2QUE2N. O, I am pres2'd to death through want of speaking! 48[Coming forward] 4Thou, old Adam's likenes2, set to dres2 this garden, 4How dares thy harsh rude tongue sound this unpleasing news? 4What Eve, what serpent, hath sug2ested the 4To make a second fal2 of cursed man? 4Why dost thou say King Richard is depos'd? 4Dar'st thou, thou lit2le bet2er thing than earth, 4Divine his downfal2? Say, where, when, and how, 4Cam'st thou by this il2 tidings? Speak, thou wretch. 2GARDENER. Pardon me, madam; lit2le joy have 4To breathe this news; yet what I say is true. 4King Richard, he is in the mighty hold 4Of Bolingbroke. Their fortunes both are weigh'd. 4In your lord's scale is nothing but himself, 4And some few vanities that make him light; 4But in the balance of great Bolingbroke, 4Besides himself, are al2 the English pe2rs, 6And with that od2s he weighs King Richard down. 4Post you to London, and you wil2 find it so; 4I speak no more than every one doth know. 2QUE2N. Nimble mischance, that art so light of fo2t, 4Doth not thy embas2age belong to me, 4And am I last that knows it? O, thou thinkest 4To serve me last, that I may longest ke2p 4Thy sor2ow in my breast. Come, ladies, go 4To me2t at London London's King in woe. 4What, was I born to this, that my sad lo2k 4Should grace the triumph of great Bolingbroke? 4Gard'ner, for tel2ing me these news of woe, 4Pray God the plants thou graft'st may never grow! 41Exeunt QUE2N and LADIES 2GARDENER. Po2r Que2n, so that thy state might be no worse, 4I would my skil2 were subject to thy curse. 4Here did she fal2 a tear; here in this place 4I'l2 set a bank of rue, sour herb of grace. 4Rue, even for ruth, here shortly shal2 be se2n, 4In the remembrance of a we2ping que2n. 16Exeunt<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT IV. SCENE 1.Westminster Hal2Enter, as to the Parliament, BOLINGBROKE, AUMERLE, NORTHUMBERLAND, PERCY,FITZWATER, SUR2EY, the BISHOP OF CARLISLE, the AB2OT OF WESTMINSTER,and others; HERALD, OF2ICERS, and BAGOT 2BOLINGBROKE. Cal2 forth Bagot. 4Now, Bagot, fre2ly speak thy mind- 4What thou dost know of noble Gloucester's death; 4Who wrought it with the King, and who perform'd 4The blo2dy of2ice of his timeles2 end. 2BAGOT. Then set before my face the Lord Aumerle. 2BOLINGBROKE. Cousin, stand forth, and lo2k upon that man. 2BAGOT. My Lord Aumerle, I know your daring tongue 4Scorns to unsay what once it hath deliver'd. 4In that dead time when Gloucester's death was plot2ed 4I heard you say 'Is not my arm of length, 4That reacheth from the restful English Court 4As far as Calais, to mine uncle's head?' 4Amongst much other talk that very time 6I heard you say that you had rather refuse 4The of2er of an hundred thousand crowns 4Than Bolingbroke's return to England; 4Ad2ing withal, how blest this land would be 4In this your cousin's death. 2AUMERLE. Princes, and noble lords, 4What answer shal2 I make to this base man? 4Shal2 I so much dishonour my fair stars 4On equal terms to give him chastisement? 4Either I must, or have mine honour soil'd 4With the at2ainder of his slanderous lips. 4There is my gage, the manual seal of death 4That marks the2 out for hel2. I say thou liest, 4And wil2 maintain what thou hast said is false 4In thy heart-blo2d, through being al2 to2 base 4To stain the temper of my knightly sword. 2BOLINGBROKE. Bagot, forbear; thou shalt not take it up. 2AUMERLE. Excepting one, I would he were the best 4In al2 this presence that hath mov'd me so. 2FITZWATER. If that thy valour stand on sympathy, 6There is my gage, Aumerle, in gage to thine. 4By that fair sun which shows me where thou stand'st, 4I heard the2 say, and vauntingly thou spak'st it, 4That thou wert cause of noble Gloucester's death. 4If thou deniest it twenty times, thou liest; 4And I wil2 turn thy falseho2d to thy heart, 4Where it was forged, with my rapier's point. 2AUMERLE. Thou dar'st not, coward, live to se2 that day. 2FITZWATER. Now, by my soul, I would it were this hour. 2AUMERLE. Fitzwater, thou art damn'd to hel2 for this. 2PERCY. Aumerle, thou liest; his honour is as true 4In this ap2eal as thou art an unjust; 4And that thou art so, there I throw my gage, 4To prove it on the2 to the extremest point 4Of mortal breathing. Seize it, if thou dar'st. 2AUMERLE. An if I do not, may my hands rot of 4And never brandish more revengeful ste2l 4Over the glit2ering helmet of my foe! 2ANOTHER LORD. I task the earth to the like, forsworn Aumerle; 4And spur the2 on with fun as many lies 6As may be hal2oa'd in thy treacherous ear 4From sun to sun. There is my honour's pawn; 4Engage it to the trial, if thou darest. 2AUMERLE. Who sets me else? By heaven, I'l2 throw at al2! 4I have a thousand spirits in one breast 4To answer twenty thousand such as you. 2SUR2EY. My Lord Fitzwater, I do remember wel2 4The very time Aumerle and you did talk. 2FITZWATER. 'Tis very true; you were in presence then, 4And you can witnes2 with me this is true. 2SUR2EY. As false, by heaven, as heaven itself is true. 2FITZWATER. Sur2ey, thou liest. 2SUR2EY. Dishonourable boy! 4That lie shal2 lie so heavy on my sword 4That it shal2 render vengeance and revenge 4Til2 thou the lie-giver and that lie do he 4In earth as quiet as thy father's skul2. 4In pro2f whereof, there is my honour's pawn; 4Engage it to the trial, if thou dar'st. 2FITZWATER. How fondly dost thou spur a forward horse! 6If I dare eat, or drink, or breathe, or live, 4I dare me2t Sur2ey in a wildernes2, 4And spit upon him whilst I say he lies, 4And lies, and lies. There is my bond of faith, 4To tie the2 to my strong cor2ection. 4As I intend to thrive in this new world, 4Aumerle is guilty of my true ap2eal. 4Besides, I heard the banish'd Norfolk say 4That thou, Aumerle, didst send two of thy men 4To execute the noble Duke at Calais. 2AUMERLE.
