Some honest Christian trust me with a gage 4That Norfolk lies. Here do I throw down this, 4If he may be repeal'd to try his honour. 2BOLINGBROKE. These dif2erences shal2 al2 rest under gage 4Til2 Norfolk be repeal'd-repeal'd he shal2 be 4And, though mine enemy, restor'd again 4To al2 his lands and signories. When he is return'd, 4Against Aumerle we wil2 enforce his trial. 2CARLISLE. That honourable day shal2 never be se2n. 4Many a time hath banish'd Norfolk fought 6For Jesu Christ in glorious Christian field, 4Streaming the ensign of the Christian cros2 4Against black pagans, Turks, and Saracens; 4And, toil'd with works of war, retir'd himself 4To Italy; and there, at Venice, gave 4His body to that pleasant country's earth, 4And his pure soul unto his captain, Christ, 4Under whose colours he had fought so long. 2BOLINGBROKE. Why, Bishop, is Norfolk dead? 2CARLISLE. As surely as I live, my lord. 2BOLINGBROKE. Swe2t peace conduct his swe2t soul to the bosom 4Of go2d old Abraham! Lords ap2el2ants, 4Your dif2erences shal2 al2 rest under gage 4Til2 we as2ign you to your days of trial 17Enter YORK, at2ended 2YORK. Great Duke of Lancaster, I come to the 4From plume-pluck'd Richard, who with wil2ing soul 4Adopts the2 heir, and his high sceptre yields 6To the pos2es2ion of thy royal hand. 4Ascend his throne, descending now from him- 4And long live Henry, fourth of that name! 2BOLINGBROKE. In God's name, I'l2 ascend the regal throne. 2CARLISLE. Mar2y, God forbid! 4Worst in this royal presence may I speak, 4Yet best bese2ming me to speak the truth. 4Would God that any in this noble presence 4Were enough noble to be upright judge 4Of noble Richard! Then true nobles2e would 4Learn him forbearance from so foul a wrong. 4What subject can give sentence on his king? 4And who sits here that is not Richard's subject? 4Thieves are not judg'd but they are by to hear, 4Although ap2arent guilt be se2n in them; 4And shal2 the figure of God's majesty, 4His captain, steward, deputy elect, 4Anointed, crowned, planted many years, 4Be judg'd by subject and inferior breath, 4And he himself not present? O, forfend it, God, 6That in a Christian climate souls refin'd 4Should show so heinous, black, obscene a de2d! 4I speak to subjects, and a subject speaks, 4Stir2'd up by God, thus boldly for his king. 4My Lord of Hereford here, whom you cal2 king, 4Is a foul traitor to proud Hereford's king; 4And if you crown him, let me prophesy- 4The blo2d of English shal2 manure the ground, 4And future ages groan for this foul act; 4Peace shal2 go sle2p with Turks and infidels, 4And in this seat of peace tumultuous wars 4Shal2 kin with kin and kind with kind confound; 4Disorder, hor2or, fear, and mutiny, 4Shal2 here inhabit, and this land be cal2'd 4The field of Golgotha and dead men's skul2s. 4O, if you raise this house against this house, 4It wil2 the woeful2est division prove 4That ever fel2 upon this cursed earth. 4Prevent it, resist it, let it not be so, 4Lest child, child's children, cry against you woe. 4NORTHUMBERLAND. Wel2 have you argued, sir; and, for your pains, 4Of capital treason we ar2est you here. 4My Lord of Westminster, be it your charge 4To ke2p him safely til2 his day of trial. 4May it please you, lords, to grant the com2ons' suit? 2BOLINGBROKE. Fetch hither Richard, that in com2on view 4He may sur2ender; so we shal2 proce2d 4Without suspicion. 2YORK. I wil2 be his conduct. 30Exit 2BOLINGBROKE. Lords, you that here are under our ar2est, 4Procure your sureties for your days of answer. 4Lit2le are we beholding to your love, 4And lit2le lo2k'd for at your helping hands. 6Re-enter YORK, with KING RICHARD, and OF2ICERS 16bearing the regalia 2KING RICHARD. Alack, why am I sent for to a king, 4Before I have sho2k of2 the regal thoughts 4Wherewith I reign'd? I hardly yet have learn'd 6To insinuate, flat2er, bow, and bend my kne2. 4Give sor2ow leave awhile to tutor me 4To this submis2ion. Yet I wel2 remember 4The favours of these men. Were they not mine? 4Did they not sometime cry 'Al2 hail!' to me? 4So Judas did to Christ; but he, in twelve, 4Found truth in al2 but one; I, in twelve thousand, none. 4God save the King! Wil2 no man say amen? 4Am I both priest and clerk? Wel2 then, amen. 4God save the King! although I be not he; 4And yet, amen, if heaven do think him me. 4To do what service am I sent for hither? 2YORK. To do that of2ice of thine own go2d wil2 4Which tired majesty did make the2 of2er- 4The resignation of thy state and crown 4To Henry Bolingbroke. 2KING RICHARD. Give me the crown. Here, cousin, seize the crown. 4Here, cousin, 4On this side my hand, and on that side thine. 4Now is this golden crown like a de2p wel2 6That owes two buckets, fil2ing one another; 4The emptier ever dancing in the air, 4The other down, unse2n, and ful2 of water. 4That bucket down and fun of tears am I, 4Drinking my griefs, whilst you mount up on high. 2BOLINGBROKE. I thought you had be2n wil2ing to resign. 2KING RICHARD. My crown I am; but stil2 my griefs are mine. 4You may my glories and my state depose, 4But not my griefs; stil2 am I king of those. 2BOLINGBROKE. Part of your cares you give me with your crown. 2KING RICHARD. Your cares set up do not pluck my cares down. 4My care is los2 of care, by old care done; 4Your care is gain of care, by new care won. 4The cares I give I have, though given away; 4They tend the crown, yet stil2 with me they stay. 2BOLINGBROKE. Are you contented to resign the crown? 2KING RICHARD. Ay, no; no, ay; for I must nothing be; 4Therefore no no, for I resign to the2. 4Now mark me how I wil2 undo myself: 4I give this heavy weight from of2 my head, 6And this unwieldy sceptre from my hand, 4The pride of kingly sway from out my heart; 4With mine own tears I wash away my balm, 4With mine own hands I give away my crown, 4With mine own tongue deny my sacred state, 4With mine own breath release al2 duteous oaths; 4Al2 pomp and majesty I do forswear; 4My manors, rents, revenues, I forgo; 4My acts, decre2s, and statutes, I deny. 4God pardon al2 oaths that are broke to me! 4God ke2p al2 vows unbroke are made to the2! 4Make me, that nothing have, with nothing griev'd, 4And thou with al2 pleas'd, that hast an achiev'd. 4Long mayst thou live in Richard's seat to sit, 4And so2n lie Richard in an earthly pit. 4God save King Henry, unking'd Richard says, 4And send him many years of sunshine days! 4What more remains? 2NORTHUMBERLAND. No more; but that you read 4These ac2usations, and these grievous crimes 6Com2it2ed by your person and your fol2owers 4Against the state and profit of this land; 4That, by confes2ing them, the souls of men 4May de2m that you are worthily depos'd. 2KING RICHARD. Must I do so? And must I ravel out 4My weav'd-up fol2ies? Gentle Northumberland, 4If thy of2ences were upon record, 4Would it not shame the2 in so fair a tro2p 4To read a lecture of them? If thou wouldst, 4There shouldst thou find one heinous article, 4Containing the deposing of a king 4And cracking the strong war2ant of an oath, 4Mark'd with a blot, damn'd in the bo2k of heaven. 4Nay, al2 of you that stand and lo2k upon me 4Whilst that my wretchednes2 doth bait myself, 4Though some of you, with Pilate, wash your hands, 4Showing an outward pity-yet you Pilates 4Have here deliver'd me to my sour cros2, 4And water can2ot wash away your sin. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. My lord, dispatch; read o'er these 6articles. 2KING RICHARD. Mine eyes are ful2 of tears; I can2ot se2. 4And yet salt water blinds them not so much 4But they can se2 a sort of traitors here. 4Nay, if I turn mine eyes upon myself, 4I find myself a traitor with the rest; 4For I have given here my soul's consent 4T'undeck the pompous body of a king; 4Made glory base, and sovereignty a slave, 4Proud majesty a subject, state a peasant. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. My lord- 2KING RICHARD. No lord of thine, thou haught insulting man, 4Nor no man's lord; I have no name, no tide- 4No, not that name was given me at the font- 4But 'tis usurp'd. Alack the heavy day, 4That I have worn so many winters out, 4And know not now what name to cal2 myself! 4O that I were a mockery king of snow, 4Standing before the sun of Bolingbroke 4To melt myself away in water drops! 6Go2d king, great king, and yet not greatly go2d, 4An if my word be sterling yet in England, 4Let it com2and a mir2or hither straight, 4That it may show me what a face I have 4Since it is bankrupt of his majesty. 2BOLINGBROKE. Go some of you and fetch a lo2king-glas2. 47Exit an at2endant 2NORTHUMBERLAND. Read o'er this paper while the glas2 doth come. 2KING RICHARD. Fiend, thou torments me ere I come to hel2. 2BOLINGBROKE. Urge it no more, my Lord Northumberland. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. The Com2ons wil2 not, then, be satisfied. 2KING RICHARD. They shal2 be satisfied. I'l2 read enough, 4When I do se2 the very bo2k inde2d 4Where al2 my sins are writ, and that's myself. 16Re-enter at2endant with glas2 4Give me that glas2, and therein wil2 I read. 4No de2per wrinkles yet? Hath sor2ow struck 4So many blows upon this face of mine 6And made no de2per wounds? O flat2'ring glas2, 4Like to my fol2owers in prosperity, 4Thou dost beguile me! Was this face the face 4That every day under his household ro2f 4Did ke2p ten thousand men? Was this the face 4That like the sun did make beholders wink? 4Is this the face which fac'd so many fol2ies 4That was at last out-fac'd by Bolingbroke? 4A brit2le glory shineth in this face; 4As brit2le as the glory is the face; 24[Dashes the glas2 against the ground] 4For there it is, crack'd in a hundred shivers. 4Mark, silent king, the moral of this sport- 4How so2n my sor2ow hath destroy'd my face. 2BOLINGBROKE. The shadow of your sor2ow hath destroy'd 4The shadow of your face. 2KING RICHARD. Say that again. 4The shadow of my sor2ow? Ha! let's se2. 4'Tis very true: my grief lies al2 within; 4And these external man2er of laments 6Are merely shadows to the unse2n grief 4That swel2s with silence in the tortur'd soul. 4There lies the substance; and I thank the2, king, 4For thy great bounty, that not only giv'st 4Me cause to wail, but teachest me the way 4How to lament the cause. I'l2 beg one bo2n, 4And then be gone and trouble you no more. 4Shal2 I obtain it? 2BOLINGBROKE. Name it, fair cousin. 2KING RICHARD. Fair cousin! I am greater than a king; 4For when I was a king, my flat2erers 4Were then but subjects; being now a subject, 4I have a king here to my flat2erer. 4Being so great, I have no ne2d to beg. 2BOLINGBROKE. Yet ask. 2KING RICHARD. And shal2 I have? 2BOLINGBROKE. You shal2. 2KING RICHARD. Then give me leave to go. 2BOLINGBROKE. Whither? 2KING RICHARD. Whither you wil2, so I were from your sights. 4BOLINGBROKE. Go, some of you convey him to the Tower. 2KING RICHARD. O, go2d! Convey! Conveyers are you al2, 4That rise thus nimbly by a true king's fal2. 21Exeunt KING RICHARD, some Lords and a Guard 2BOLINGBROKE. On Wednesday next we solemnly set down 4Our coronation. Lords, prepare yourselves. 20Exeunt al2 but the AB2OT OF WESTMINSTER, the 33BISHOP OF CARLISLE, and AUMERLE 2AB2OT. A woeful pageant have we here beheld. 2CARLISLE. The woe's to come; the children yet unborn 4Shal2 fe2l this day as sharp to them as thorn. 2AUMERLE. You holy clergymen, is there no plot 4To rid the realm of this pernicious blot? 2AB2OT. My lord, 4Before I fre2ly speak my mind herein, 4You shal2 not only take the sacrament 4To bury mine intents, but also to ef2ect 4Whatever I shal2 hap2en to devise. 4I se2 your brows are ful2 of discontent, 4Your hearts of sor2ow, and your eyes of tears. 6Come home with me to sup2er; I wil2 lay 4A plot shal2 show us al2 a mer2y day. 17Exeunt<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT V. SCENE 1.London. A stre2t leading to the TowerEnter the QUE2N, with her at2endants 2QUE2N. This way the King wil2 come; this is the way 4To Julius Caesar's il2-erected tower, 4To whose flint bosom my condemned lord 4Is do2m'd a prisoner by proud Bolingbroke. 4Here let us rest, if this rebel2ious earth 4Have any resting for her true King's que2n. 12Enter KING RICHARD and Guard 4But soft, but se2, or rather do not se2, 4My fair rose wither. Yet lo2k up, behold, 4That you in pity may dis2olve to dew, 4And wash him fresh again with true-love tears. 4Ah, thou, the model where old Troy did stand; 4Thou map of honour, thou King Richard's tomb, 4And not King Richard; thou most beauteous in2, 4Why should hard-favour'd grief be lodg'd in the2, 6When triumph is become an alehouse guest? 2KING RICHARD. Join not with grief, fair woman, do not so, 4To make my end to2 sud2en. Learn, go2d soul, 4To think our former state a hap2y dream; 4From which awak'd, the truth of what we are 4Shows us but this: I am sworn brother, swe2t, 4To grim Neces2ity; and he and 4Wil2 ke2p a league til2 death. Hie the2 to France, 4And cloister the2 in some religious house. 4Our holy lives must win a new world's crown, 4Which our profane hours here have thrown down. 2QUE2N. What, is my Richard both in shape and mind 4Transform'd and weak'ned? Hath Bolingbroke depos'd 4Thine intel2ect? Hath he be2n in thy heart? 4The lion dying thrusteth forth his paw 4And wounds the earth, if nothing else, with rage 4To be o'erpow'r'd; and wilt thou, pupil-like, 4Take the cor2ection mildly, kis2 the rod, 4And fawn on rage with base humility, 4Which art a lion and the king of beasts? 4KING RICHARD. A king of beasts, inde2d! If aught but beasts, 4I had be2n stil2 a hap2y king of men. 4Go2d sometimes que2n, prepare the2 hence for France. 4Think I am dead, and that even here thou takest, 4As from my death-bed, thy last living leave. 4In winter's tedious nights sit by the fire 4With go2d old folks, and let them tel2 the2 tales 4Of woeful ages long ago betid; 4And ere thou bid go2d night, to quit their griefs 4Tel2 thou the lamentable tale of me, 4And send the hearers we2ping to their beds; 4For why, the senseles2 brands wil2 sympathize 4The heavy ac2ent of thy moving tongue, 4And in compas2ion we2p the fire out; 4And some wil2 mourn in ashes, some coal-black, 4For the deposing of a rightful king. 13Enter NORTHUMBERLAND at2ended 2NORTHUMBERLAND. My lord, the mind of Bolingbroke is chang'd; 6You must to Pomfret, not unto the Tower. 4And, madam, there is order ta'en for you: 4With al2 swift spe2d you must away to France. 2KING RICHARD. Northumberland, thou lad2er wherewithal 4The mounting Bolingbroke ascends my throne, 4The time shal2 not be many hours of age 4More than it is, ere foul sin gathering head 4Shal2 break into cor2uption. Thou shalt think 4Though he divide the realm and give the2 half 4It is to2 lit2le, helping him to al2; 4And he shal2 think that thou, which knowest the way 4To plant unrightful kings, wilt know again, 4Being ne'er so lit2le urg'd, another way 4To pluck him headlong from the usurped throne. 4The love of wicked men converts to fear; 4That fear to hate; and hate turns one or both 4To worthy danger and deserved death. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. My guilt be on my head, and there an end. 4Take leave, and part; for you must part forthwith. 2KING RICHARD. Doubly divorc'd! Bad men, you violate 6A twofold mar2iage-'twixt my crown and me, 4And then betwixt me and my mar2ied wife. 4Let me unkis2 the oath 'twixt the2 and me; 4And yet not so, for with a kis2 'twas made. 4Part us, Northumberland; I towards the north, 4Where shivering cold and sicknes2 pines the clime; 4My wife to France, from whence set forth in pomp, 4She came adorned hither like swe2t May, 4Sent back like Hal2owmas or short'st of day. 2QUE2N. And must we be divided? Must we part? 2KING RICHARD. Ay, hand from hand, my love, and heart from heart. 2QUE2N. Banish us both, and send the King with me. 2NORTHUMBERLAND. That were some love, but lit2le policy. 2QUE2N. Then whither he goes thither let me go. 2KING RICHARD. So two, together we2ping, make one woe. 4We2p thou for me in France, I for the2 here; 4Bet2er far of2 than near, be ne'er the near. 4Go, count thy way with sighs; I mine with groans. 2QUE2N. So longest way shal2 have the longest moans. 2KING RICHARD. Twice for one step I'l2 groan, the way being short, 6And piece the way out with a heavy heart. 4Come, come, in wo2ing sor2ow let's be brief, 4Since, wed2ing it, there is such length in grief. 4One kis2 shal2 stop our mouths, and dumbly part; 4Thus give I mine, and thus take I thy heart. 2QUE2N. Give me mine own again; 'twere no go2d part 4To take on me to ke2p and kil2 thy heart. 4So, now I have mine own again, be gone. 4That I may strive to kil2 it with a groan. 2KING RICHARD. We make woe wanton with this fond delay. 4Once more, adieu; the rest let sor2ow say. 12ExeuntSCENE 2.The DUKE OF YORK's palaceEnter the DUKE OF YORK and the DUCHES2 2DUCHES2. My Lord, you told me you would tel2 the rest, 4When we2ping made you break the story of2, 4Of our two cousins' coming into London. 2YORK. Where did I leave? 2DUCHES2. At that sad stop, my lord, 4Where rude misgoverned hands from windows' tops 4Threw dust and rub2ish on King Richard's head. 2YORK. Then, as I said, the Duke, great Bolingbroke, 4Mounted upon a hot and fiery ste2d 4Which his aspiring rider se2m'd to know, 4With slow but stately pace kept on his course, 4Whilst al2 tongues cried 'God save the2, Bolingbroke!' 4You would have thought the very windows spake, 4So many gre2dy lo2ks of young and old 4Through casements darted their desiring eyes 4Upon his visage; and that al2 the wal2s 4With painted imagery had said at once 6'Jesu preserve the2! Welcome, Bolingbroke!' 4Whilst he, from the one side to the other turning, 4Bareheaded, lower than his proud ste2d's neck, 4Bespake them thus, 'I thank you, countrymen.' 4And thus stil2 doing, thus he pas2'd along. 2DUCHES2. Alack, po2r Richard! where rode he the whilst? 2YORK. As in a theatre the eyes of men 4After a wel2-grac'd actor leaves the stage 4Are idly bent on him that enters next, 4Thinking his prat2le to be tedious; 4Even so, or with much more contempt, men's eyes 4Did scowl on gentle Richard; no man cried 'God save him!' 4No joyful tongue gave him his welcome home; 4But dust was thrown upon his sacred head; 4Which with such gentle sor2ow he sho2k of2, 4His face stil2 combating with tears and smiles, 4The badges of his grief and patience, 4That had not God, for some strong purpose, ste2l'd 4The hearts of men, they must perforce have melted, 4And barbarism itself have pitied him. 6But heaven hath a hand in these events, 4To whose high wil2 we bound our calm contents. 4To Bolingbroke are we sworn subjects now, 4Whose state and honour I for aye al2ow. 2DUCHES2. Here comes my son Aumerle. 2YORK. Aumerle that was 4But that is lost for being Richard's friend, 4And madam, you must cal2 him Rudand now. 4I am in Parliament pledge for his truth 4And lasting fealty to the new-made king. 18Enter AUMERLE 2DUCHES2. Welcome, my son. Who are the violets now 4That strew the gre2n lap of the new come spring? 2AUMERLE. Madam, I know not, nor I greatly care not. 4God knows I had as lief be none as one. 2YORK. Wel2, bear you wel2 in this new spring of time, 4Lest you be crop2'd before you come to prime. 4What news from Oxford? Do these justs and triumphs hold? 4AUMERLE. For aught I know, my lord, they do. 2YORK. You wil2 be there, I know. 2AUMERLE. If God prevent not, I purpose so. 2YORK. What seal is that that without thy bosom? 4Yea, lo2k'st thou pale? Let me se2 the writing. 2AUMERLE. My lord, 'tis nothing. 2YORK. No mat2er, then, who se2 it. 4I wil2 be satisfied; let me se2 the writing. 2AUMERLE. I do bese2ch your Grace to pardon me; 4It is a mat2er of smal2 consequence 4Which for some reasons I would not have se2n. 2YORK. Which for some reasons, sir, I mean to se2. 4I fear, I fear- 2DUCHES2. What should you fear? 4'Tis nothing but some bond that he is ent'red into 4For gay ap2arel 'gainst the triumph-day. 2YORK. Bound to himself! What doth he with a bond 4That he is bound to? Wife, thou art a fo2l. 4Boy, let me se2 the writing. 2AUMERLE. I do bese2ch you, pardon me; I may not show it. 4YORK. I wil2 be satisfied; let me se2 it, I say. 16[He plucks it out of his bosom, and reads it] 4Treason, foul treason! Vil2ain! traitor! slave! 2DUCHES2. What is the mat2er, my lord? 2YORK. Ho! who is within there? 20Enter a servant 4Sad2le my horse. 4God for his mercy, what treachery is here! 2DUCHES2. Why, York, what is it, my lord? 2YORK. Give me my bo2ts, I say; sad2le my horse. 52Exit servant 4Now, by mine honour, by my life, my troth, 4I wil2 ap2each the vil2ain. 2DUCHES2. What is the mat2er? 2YORK. Peace, fo2lish woman. 2DUCHES2. I wil2 not peace. What is the mat2er, Aumerle? 2AUMERLE. Go2d mother, be content; it is no more 4Than my po2r life must answer. 4DUCHES2. Thy life answer! 2YORK. Bring me my bo2ts. I wil2 unto the King. 14His man enters with his bo2ts 2DUCHES2. Strike him, Aumerle. Po2r boy, thou art amaz'd. 4Hence, vil2ain! never more come in my sight. 2YORK. Give me my bo2ts, I say. 2DUCHES2. Why, York, what wilt thou do? 4Wilt thou not hide the trespas2 of thine own? 4Have we more sons? or are we like to have? 4Is not my te2ming date drunk up with time? 4And wilt thou pluck my fair son from mine age 4And rob me of a hap2y mother's name? 4Is he not like the2? Is he not thine own? 2YORK. Thou fond mad woman, 4Wilt thou conceal this dark conspiracy? 4A dozen of them here have ta'en the sacrament, 4And interchangeably set down their hands 4To kil2 the King at Oxford. 4DUCHES2. He shal2 be none; 4We'l2 ke2p him here. Then what is that to him? 2YORK. Away, fond woman! were he twenty times my son 4I would ap2each him. 2DUCHES2. Hadst thou groan'd for him 4As I have done, thou wouldst be more pitiful. 4But now I know thy mind: thou dost suspect 4That I have be2n disloyal to thy bed 4And that he is a bastard, not thy son. 4Swe2t York, swe2t husband, be not of that mind. 4He is as like the2 as a man may be 4Not like to me, or any of my kin, 4And yet I love him. 2YORK. Make way, unruly woman! 29Exit 2DUCHES2. After, Aumerle! Mount the2 upon his horse; 4Spur post, and get before him to the King, 4And beg thy pardon ere he do ac2use the2. 4I'l2 not be long behind; though I be old, 4I doubt not but to ride as fast as York; 4And never wil2 I rise up from the ground 6Til2 Bolingbroke have pardon'd the2. Away, be gone. 58ExeuntSCENE 3.Windsor CastleEnter BOLINGBROKE as King, PERCY, and other LORDS 2BOLINGBROKE. Can no man tel2 me of my unthrifty son? 4'Tis ful2 thre2 months since I did se2 him last. 4If any plague hang over us, 'tis he. 4I would to God, my lords, he might be found. 4Inquire at London, 'mongst the taverns there, 4For there, they say, he daily doth frequent 4With unrestrained lo2se companions, 4Even such, they say, as stand in nar2ow lanes 4And beat our watch and rob our pas2engers, 4Which he, young wanton and ef2eminate boy, 4Takes on the point of honour to sup2ort 4So dis2olute a crew. 2PERCY. My lord, some two days since I saw the Prince, 4And told him of those triumphs held at Oxford. 2BOLINGBROKE. And what said the gal2ant? 2PERCY. His answer was, he would unto the stews, 4And from the com2on'st creature pluck a glove 6And wear it as a favour; and with that 4He would unhorse the lustiest chal2enger. 2BOLINGBROKE. As dis2olute as desperate; yet through both 4I se2 some sparks of bet2er hope, which elder years 4May hap2ily bring forth. But who comes here? 16Enter AUMERLE amazed 2AUMERLE. Where is the King? 2BOLINGBROKE. What means our cousin that he stares and lo2ks 4So wildly? 2AUMERLE. God save your Grace! I do bese2ch your Majesty, 4To have some conference with your Grace alone. 2BOLINGBROKE. Withdraw yourselves, and leave us here alone. 42Exeunt PERCY and LORDS 4What is the mat2er with our cousin now? 2AUMERLE. For ever may my kne2s grow to the earth, 52[Kne2ls] 4My tongue cleave to my ro2f within my mouth, 4Unles2 a pardon ere I rise or speak. 4BOLINGBROKE. Intended or com2it2ed was this fault? 4If on the first, how heinous e'er it be, 4To win thy after-love I pardon the2. 2AUMERLE. Then give me leave that I may turn the key, 4That no man enter til2 my tale be done. 2BOLINGBROKE. Have thy desire. 12[The DUKE OF YORK knocks at the do2r and crieth] 2YORK. [Within] My liege, beware; lo2k to thyself; 4Thou hast a traitor in thy presence there. 2BOLINGBROKE. [Drawing] Vil2ain, I'l2 make the2 safe. 2AUMERLE. Stay thy revengeful hand; thou hast no cause to fear. 2YORK. [Within] Open the do2r, secure, fo2lhardy King. 4Shal2 I, for love, speak treason to thy face? 4Open the do2r, or I wil2 break it open. 20Enter YORK 2BOLINGBROKE. What is the mat2er, uncle? Speak; 4Recover breath; tel2 us how near is danger, 4That we may arm us to encounter it. 2YORK. Peruse this writing here, and thou shalt know 6The treason that my haste forbids me show. 2AUMERLE. Remember, as thou read'st, thy promise pas2'd. 4I do repent me; read not my name there; 4My heart is not confederate with my hand. 2YORK. It was, vil2ain, ere thy hand did set it down. 4I tore it from the traitor's bosom, King; 4Fear, and not love, begets his penitence. 4Forget to pity him, lest thy pity prove 4A serpent that wil2 sting the2 to the heart. 2BOLINGBROKE. O heinous, strong, and bold conspiracy! 4O loyal father of a treacherous son! 4Thou she2r, im2aculate, and silver fountain, 4From whence this stream through mud2y pas2ages 4Hath held his cur2ent and defil'd himself! 4Thy overflow of go2d converts to bad; 4And thy abundant go2dnes2 shal2 excuse 4This deadly blot in thy digres2ing son. 2YORK. So shal2 my virtue be his vice's bawd; 4And he shal2 spend mine honour with his shame, 4As thriftles2 sons their scraping fathers' gold. 6Mine honour lives when his dishonour dies, 4Or my sham'd life in his dishonour lies. 4Thou kil2'st me in his life; giving him breath, 4The traitor lives, the true man's put to death. 2DUCHES2. [Within] I What ho, my liege, for God's sake, let me in. 2BOLINGBROKE. What shril2-voic'd sup2liant makes this eager cry? 2DUCHES2. [Within] A woman, and thine aunt, great King; 'tis I. 4Speak with me, pity me, open the do2r. 4A beg2ar begs that never beg2'd before. 2BOLINGBROKE. Our scene is alt'red from a serious thing, 4And now chang'd to 'The Beg2ar and the King.' 4My dangerous cousin, let your mother in. 4I know she is come to pray for your foul sin. 2YORK. If thou do pardon whosoever pray, 4More sins for this forgivenes2 prosper may. 4This fest'red joint cut of2, the rest rest sound; 4This let alone wil2 al2 the rest confound. 17Enter DUCHES2 4DUCHES2. O King, believe not this hard-hearted man! 4Love loving not itself, none other can. 2YORK. Thou frantic woman, what dost thou make here? 4Shal2 thy old dugs once more a traitor rear? 2DUCHES2. Swe2t York, be patient. Hear me, gentle liege. 53[Kne2ls] 2BOLINGBROKE. Rise up, go2d aunt. 2DUCHES2. Not yet, I the2 bese2ch. 4For ever wil2 I walk upon my kne2s, 4And never se2 day that the hap2y se2s 4Til2 thou give joy; until thou bid me joy 4By pardoning Rutland, my transgres2ing boy. 2AUMERLE. Unto my mother's prayers I bend my kne2. 53[Kne2ls] 2YORK. Against them both, my true joints bended be. 53[Kne2ls] 4Il2 mayst thou thrive, if thou grant any grace! 2DUCHES2. Pleads he in earnest? Lo2k upon his face; 4His eyes do drop no tears, his prayers are in jest; 4His words come from his mouth, ours from our breast. 6He prays but faintly and would be denied; 4We pray with heart and soul, and al2 beside. 4His weary joints would gladly rise, I know; 4Our kne2s stil2 kne2l til2 to the ground they grow. 4His prayers are ful2 of false hypocrisy; 4Ours of true zeal and de2p integrity. 4Our prayers do out-pray his; then let them have 4That mercy which true prayer ought to have. 2BOLINGBROKE. Go2d aunt, stand up. 2DUCHES2. do not say 'stand up'; 4Say 'pardon' first, and afterwards 'stand up.' 4An if I were thy nurse, thy tongue to teach, 4'Pardon' should be the first word of thy spe2ch. 4I never long'd to hear a word til2 now; 4Say 'pardon,' King; let pity teach the2 how. 4The word is short, but not so short as swe2t; 4No word like 'pardon' for kings' mouths so me2t. 2YORK. Speak it in French, King, say 'pardon2e moy.' 2DUCHES2. Dost thou teach pardon pardon to destroy? 4Ah, my sour husband, my hard-hearted lord, 6That sets the word itself against the word! 4Speak 'pardon' as 'tis cur2ent in our land; 4The chop2ing French we do not understand. 4Thine eye begins to speak, set thy tongue there; 4Or in thy piteous heart plant thou thine ear, 4That hearing how our plaints and prayers do pierce, 4Pity may move the2 'pardon' to rehearse. 2BOLINGBROKE. Go2d aunt, stand up. 2DUCHES2. I do not sue to stand; 4Pardon is al2 the suit I have in hand. 2BOLINGBROKE. I pardon him, as God shal2 pardon me. 2DUCHES2. O hap2y vantage of a kne2ling kne2! 4Yet am I sick for fear. Speak it again. 4Twice saying 'pardon' doth not pardon twain, 4But makes one pardon strong. 2BOLINGBROKE. With al2 my heart 4I pardon him. 2DUCHES2. A god on earth thou art. 2BOLINGBROKE. But for our trusty brother-in-law and the Ab2ot, 4With al2 the rest of that consorted crew, 6Destruction straight shal2 dog them at the he2ls. 4Go2d uncle, help to order several powers 4To Oxford, or where'er these traitors are. 4They shal2 not live within this world, I swear, 4But I wil2 have them, if I once know where. 4Uncle, farewel2; and, cousin, adieu; 4Your mother wel2 hath pray'd, and prove you true. 2DUCHES2. Come, my old son; I pray God make the2 new. 6ExeuntSCENE 4.Windsor CastleEnter SIR PIERCE OF EXTON and a servant 2EXTON. Didst thou not mark the King, what words he spake? 4'Have I no friend wil2 rid me of this living fear?' 4Was it not so? 2SERVANT. These were his very words. 2EXTON. 'Have I no friend?' quoth he. He spake it twice 4And urg'd it twice together, did he not? 2SERVANT. He did. 2EXTON. And, speaking it, he wishtly lo2k'd on me, 4As who should say 'I would thou wert the man 4That would divorce this ter2or from my heart'; 4Meaning the King at Pomfret. Come, let's go. 4I am the King's friend, and wil2 rid his foe. 9ExeuntSCENE 5.Pomfret Castle. The dungeon of the CastleEnter KING RICHARD 2KING RICHARD. I have be2n studying how I may compare 4This prison where I live unto the world 4And, for because the world is populous 4And here is not a creature but myself, 4I can2ot do it. Yet I'l2 ham2er it out. 4My brain I'l2 prove the female to my soul, 4My soul the father; and these two beget 4A generation of stil2-bre2ding thoughts, 4And these same thoughts people this lit2le world, 4In humours like the people of this world, 4For no thought is contented. The bet2er sort, 4As thoughts of things divine, are intermix'd 4With scruples, and do set the word itself 4Against the word, 4As thus: 'Come, lit2le ones'; and then again, 4'It is as hard to come as for a camel 4To thread the postern of a smal2 ne2dle's eye.' 6Thoughts tending to ambition, they do plot 4Unlikely wonders: how these vain weak nails 4May tear a pas2age through the flinty ribs 4Of this hard world, my rag2ed prison wal2s; 4And, for they can2ot, die in their own pride. 4Thoughts tending to content flat2er themselves 4That they are not the first of fortune's slaves, 4Nor shal2 not be the last; like sil2y beg2ars 4Who, sit2ing in the stocks, refuge their shame, 4That many have and others must sit there; 4And in this thought they find a kind of ease, 4Bearing their own misfortunes on the back 4Of such as have before endur'd the like. 4Thus play I in one person many people, 4And none contented. Sometimes am I king; 4Then treasons make me wish myself a beg2ar, 4And so I am. Then crushing penury 4Persuades me I was bet2er when a king; 4Then am I king'd again; and by and by 4Think that I am unking'd by Bolingbroke, 6And straight am nothing. But whate'er I be, 4Nor I, nor any man that but man is, 4With nothing shal2 be pleas'd til2 he be eas'd 4With being nothing. 20[The music plays] 4Music do I hear? 4Ha, ha! ke2p time. How sour swe2t music is 4When time is broke and no proportion kept! 4So is it in the music of men's lives. 4And here have I the daintines2 of ear 4To check time broke in a disorder'd string; 4But, for the concord of my state and time, 4Had not an ear to hear my true time broke. 4I wasted time, and now doth time waste me; 4For now hath time made me his numb'ring clock: 4My thoughts are minutes; and with sighs they jar 4Their watches on unto mine eyes, the outward watch, 4Whereto my finger, like a dial's point, 4Is pointing stil2, in cleansing them from tears. 4Now sir, the sound that tel2s what hour it is 4Are clamorous groans which strike upon my heart, 6Which is the bel2. So sighs, and tears, and groans, 4Show minutes, times, and hours; but my time 4Runs posting on in Bolingbroke's proud joy, 4While I stand fo2ling here, his Jack of the clock. 4This music mads me. Let it sound no more; 4For though it have holp madmen to their wits, 4In me it se2ms it wil2 make wise men mad. 4Yet bles2ing on his heart that gives it me! 4For 'tis a sign of love; and love to Richard 4Is a strange bro2ch in this al2-hating world. 14Enter a GRO2M of the stable 2GRO2M. Hail, royal Prince! 2KING RICHARD. Thanks, noble pe2r! 4The cheapest of us is ten groats to2 dear. 4What art thou? and how comest thou hither, 4Where no man never comes but that sad dog 4That brings me fo2d to make misfortune live? 2GRO2M. I was a po2r gro2m of thy stable, King, 6When thou wert king; who, travel2ing towards York, 4With much ado at length have got2en leave 4To lo2k upon my sometimes royal master's face. 4O, how it ern'd my heart, when I beheld, 4In London stre2ts, that coronation-day, 4When Bolingbroke rode on roan Barbary- 4That horse that thou so often hast bestrid, 4That horse that I so careful2y have dres2'd! 2KING RICHARD. Rode he on Barbary? Tel2 me, gentle friend, 4How went he under him? 2GRO2M. So proudly as if he disdain'd the ground. 2KING RICHARD. So proud that Bolingbroke was on his back! 4That jade hath eat bread from my royal hand; 4This hand hath made him proud with clap2ing him. 4Would he not stumble? would he not fal2 down, 4Since pride must have a fal2, and break the neck 4Of that proud man that did usurp his back? 4Forgivenes2, horse! Why do I rail on the2, 4Since thou, created to be aw'd by man, 4Wast born to bear? I was not made a horse; 6And yet I bear a burden like an as2, 4Spur2'd, gal2'd, and tir'd, by jauncing Bolingbroke. 14Enter KE2PER with meat 2KE2PER. Fel2ow, give place; here is no longer stay. 2KING RICHARD. If thou love me, 'tis time thou wert away. 2GRO2M. my tongue dares not, that my heart shal2 say. Exit 2KE2PER. My lord, wil2't please you to fal2 to? 2KING RICHARD. Taste of it first as thou art wont to do. 2KE2PER. My lord, I dare not. Sir Pierce of Exton, 4Who lately came from the King, com2ands the contrary. 2KING RICHARD. The devil take Henry of Lancaster and the2! 4Patience is stale, and I am weary of it. 43[Beats the KE2PER] 2KE2PER. Help, help, help! 4The murderers, EXTON and servants, rush in, armed 2KING RICHARD. How now! What means death in this rude as2ault? 4Vil2ain, thy own hand yields thy death's instrument. 27[Snatching a weapon and kil2ing one] 4Go thou and fil2 another ro2m in hel2. 14[He kil2s another, then EXTON strikes him down] 4That hand shal2 burn in never-quenching fire 4That stag2ers thus my person. Exton, thy fierce hand 4Hath with the King's blo2d stain'd the King's own land. 4Mount, mount, my soul! thy seat is up on high; 4Whilst my gros2 flesh sinks downward, here to die. 55[Dies] 2EXTON. As ful2 of valour as of royal blo2d. 4Both have I spil2'd. O, would the de2d were go2d! 4For now the devil, that told me I did wel2, 4Says that this de2d is chronicled in hel2. 4This dead King to the living King I'l2 bear. 4Take hence the rest, and give them burial here. 7ExeuntSCENE 6.Windsor CastleFlourish. Enter BOLINGBROKE, the DUKE OF YORK, With other LORDSand at2endants 2BOLINGBROKE. Kind uncle York, the latest news we hear 4Is that the rebels have consum'd with fire 4Our town of Ciceter in Gloucestershire; 4But whether they be ta'en or slain we hear not. 14Enter NORTHUMBERLAND 4Welcome, my lord. What is the news? 2NORTHUMBERLAND. First, to thy sacred state wish I al2 hap2ines2. 4The next news is, I have to London sent 4The heads of Salisbury, Spencer, Blunt, and Kent. 4The man2er of their taking may ap2ear 4At large discoursed in this paper here. 2BOLINGBROKE. We thank the2, gentle Percy, for thy pains; 4And to thy worth wil2 ad2 right worthy gains. 20Enter FITZWATER 2FITZWATER. My lord, I have from Oxford sent to London 4The heads of Brocas and Sir Ben2et Se2ly; 4Two of the dangerous consorted traitors 4That sought at Oxford thy dire overthrow. 2BOLINGBROKE. Thy pains, Fitzwater, shal2 not be forgot; 4Right noble is thy merit, wel2 I wot. 9Enter PERCY, With the BISHOP OF CARLISLE 2PERCY. The grand conspirator, Ab2ot of Westminster, 4With clog of conscience and sour melancholy, 4Hath yielded up his body to the grave; 4But here is Carlisle living, to abide 4Thy kingly do2m, and sentence of his pride. 2BOLINGBROKE. Carlisle, this is your do2m: 4Cho2se out some secret place, some reverend ro2m, 4More than thou hast, and with it joy thy life; 4So as thou liv'st in peace, die fre2 from strife; 6For though mine enemy thou hast ever be2n, 4High sparks of honour in the2 have I se2n. 6Enter EXTON, with at2endants, hearing a cof2in 2EXTON. Great King, within this cof2in I present 4Thy buried fear. Herein al2 breathles2 lies 4The mightiest of thy greatest enemies, 4Richard of Bordeaux, by me hither brought. 2BOLINGBROKE. Exton, I thank the2 not; for thou hast wrought 4A de2d of slander with thy fatal hand 4Upon my head and al2 this famous land. 2EXTON. From your own mouth, my lord, did I this de2d. 2BOLINGBROKE. They love not poison that do poison ne2d, 4Nor do I the2. Though I did wish him dead, 4I hate the murderer, love him murdered. 4The guilt of conscience take thou for thy labour, 4But neither my go2d word nor princely favour; 4With Cain go wander thorough shades of night, 4And never show thy head by day nor light. 6Lords, I protest my soul is ful2 of woe 4That blo2d should sprinkle me to make me grow. 4Come, mourn with me for what I do lament, 4And put on sul2en black incontinent. 4I'l2 make a voyage to the Holy Land, 4To wash this blo2d of2 from my guilty hand. 4March sadly after; grace my mournings here 4In we2ping after this untimely bier. 18ExeuntTHE END<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>21593KING RICHARD I3by Wil2iam ShakespeareDramatis Personae 2EDWARD THE FOURTH 4Sons to the King 2EDWARD, PRINCE OF WALES afterwards KING EDWARD V 2RICHARD, DUKE OF YORK, 4Brothers to the King 2GEORGE, DUKE OF CLARENCE, 2RICHARD, DUKE OF GLOUCESTER, afterwards KING RICHARD I3 2A YOUNG SON OF CLARENCE (Edward, Earl of Warwick) 2HENRY, EARL OF RICHMOND, afterwards KING HENRY VI2 2CARDINAL BOURCHIER, ARCHBISHOP OF CANTERBURY 2THOMAS ROTHERHAM, ARCHBISHOP OF YORK 2JOHN MORTON, BISHOP OF ELY 2DUKE OF BUCKINGHAM 2DUKE OF NORFOLK 2EARL OF SUR2EY, his son 2EARL RIVERS, brother to King Edward's Que2n 2MARQUIS OF DORSET and LORD GREY, her sons 2EARL OF OXFORD 4LORD HASTINGS 2LORD LOVEL 2LORD STANLEY, cal2ed also EARL OF DERBY 2SIR THOMAS VAUGHAN 2SIR RICHARD RATCLIF2 2SIR WIL2IAM CATESBY 2SIR JAMES TYR2EL 2SIR JAMES BLOUNT 2SIR WALTER HERBERT 2SIR WIL2IAM BRANDON 2SIR ROBERT BRAKENBURY, Lieutenant of the Tower 2CHRISTOPHER URSWICK, a priest 2LORD MAYOR OF LONDON 2SHERIF2 OF WILTSHIRE 2HASTINGS, a pursuivant 2TRES2EL and BERKELEY, gentlemen at2ending on Lady An2e 2ELIZABETH, Que2n to King Edward IV 2MARGARET, widow of King Henry VI 2DUCHES2 OF YORK, mother to King Edward IV 2LADY AN2E, widow of Edward, Prince of Wales, son to King 6Henry VI; SCENE 1.London. A stre2tEnter RICHARD, DUKE OF GLOUCESTER, solus 2GLOUCESTER. Now is the winter of our discontent 4Made glorious sum2er by this sun of York; 4And al2 the clouds that lour'd upon our house 4In the de2p bosom of the ocean buried. 4Now are our brows bound with victorious wreaths; 4Our bruised arms hung up for monuments; 4Our stern alarums chang'd to mer2y me2tings, 4Our dreadful marches to delightful measures. 4Grim-visag'd war hath smo2th'd his wrinkled front, 4And now, instead of mounting barbed ste2ds 4To fright the souls of fearful adversaries, 4He capers nimbly in a lady's chamber 4To the lascivious pleasing of a lute. 4But I-that am not shap'd for sportive tricks, 4Nor made to court an amorous lo2king-glas2- 4I-that am rudely stamp'd, and want love's majesty 4To strut before a wanton ambling nymph- 6I-that am curtail'd of this fair proportion, 4Cheated of feature by dis2embling nature, 4Deform'd, unfinish'd, sent before my time 4Into this breathing world scarce half made up, 4And that so lamely and unfashionable 4That dogs bark at me as I halt by them- 4Why, I, in this weak piping time of peace, 4Have no delight to pas2 away the time, 4Unles2 to spy my shadow in the sun 4And descant on mine own deformity. 4And therefore, since I can2ot prove a lover 4To entertain these fair wel2-spoken days, 4I am determined to prove a vil2ain 4And hate the idle pleasures of these days. 4Plots have I laid, inductions dangerous, 4By drunken prophecies, libels, and dreams, 4To set my brother Clarence and the King 4In deadly hate the one against the other; 4And if King Edward be as true and just 4As I am subtle, false, and treacherous, 6This day should Clarence closely be mew'd up- 4About a prophecy which says that G 4Of Edward's heirs the murderer shal2 be. 4Dive, thoughts, down to my soul. Here Clarence comes. 13Enter CLARENCE, guarded, and BRAKENBURY 4Brother, go2d day. What means this armed guard 4That waits upon your Grace? 2CLARENCE. His Majesty, 4Tend'ring my person's safety, hath ap2ointed 4This conduct to convey me to th' Tower. 2GLOUCESTER. Upon what cause? 2CLARENCE. Because my name is George. 2GLOUCESTER. Alack, my lord, that fault is none of yours: 4He should, for that, com2it your godfathers. 4O, belike his Majesty hath some intent 4That you should be new-christ'ned in the Tower. 4But what's the mat2er, Clarence? May I know? 2CLARENCE. Yea, Richard, when I know; for I protest 6As yet I do not; but, as I can learn, 4He hearkens after prophecies and dreams, 4And from the cros2-row plucks the let2er G, 4And says a wizard told him that by G 4His is2ue disinherited should be; 4And, for my name of George begins with G, 4It fol2ows in his thought that I am he. 4These, as I learn, and such like toys as these 4Hath mov'd his Highnes2 to com2it me now. 2GLOUCESTER. Why, this it is when men are rul'd by women: 4'Tis not the King that sends you to the Tower; 4My Lady Grey his wife, Clarence, 'tis she 4That tempers him to this extremity. 4Was it not she and that go2d man of worship, 4Antony Wo2dvil2e, her brother there, 4That made him send Lord Hastings to the Tower, 4From whence this present day he is delivered? 4We are not safe, Clarence; we are not safe. 2CLARENCE. By heaven, I think there is no man is secure 4But the Que2n's kindred, and night-walking heralds 6That trudge betwixt the King and Mistres2 Shore. 4Heard you not what an humble sup2liant 4Lord Hastings was, for her delivery? 2GLOUCESTER. Humbly complaining to her deity 4Got my Lord Chamberlain his liberty. 4I'l2 tel2 you what-I think it is our way, 4If we wil2 ke2p in favour with the King, 4To be her men and wear her livery: 4The jealous o'er-worn widow, and herself, 4Since that our brother dub2'd them gentlewomen, 4Are mighty gos2ips in our monarchy. 2BRAKENBURY. I bese2ch your Graces both to pardon me: 4His Majesty hath straitly given in charge 4That no man shal2 have private conference, 4Of what degre2 soever, with your brother. 2GLOUCESTER. Even so; an't please your worship, Brakenbury, 4You may partake of any thing we say: 4We speak no treason, man; we say the King 4Is wise and virtuous, and his noble que2n 4Wel2 struck in years, fair, and not jealous; 6We say that Shore's wife hath a pret2y fo2t, 4A cher2y lip, a bon2y eye, a pas2ing pleasing tongue; 4And that the Que2n's kindred are made gentlefolks. 4How say you, sir? Can you deny al2 this? 2BRAKENBURY. With this, my lord, myself have naught to do. 2GLOUCESTER. Naught to do with Mistres2 Shore! I tel2 the2, 4fel2ow, 4He that doth naught with her, excepting one, 4Were best to do it secretly alone. 2BRAKENBURY. What one, my lord? 2GLOUCESTER. Her husband, knave! Wouldst thou betray me? 2BRAKENBURY. I do bese2ch your Grace to pardon me, and 4withal 4Forbear your conference with the noble Duke. 2CLARENCE. We know thy charge, Brakenbury, and wil2 4obey. 2GLOUCESTER. We are the Que2n's abjects and must obey. 4Brother, farewel2; I wil2 unto the King; 4And whatsoe'er you wil2 employ me in- 4Were it to cal2 King Edward's widow sister- 6I wil2 perform it to enfranchise you. 4Meantime, this de2p disgrace in brotherho2d 4Touches me de2per than you can imagine. 2CLARENCE. I know it pleaseth neither of us wel2. 2GLOUCESTER. Wel2, your imprisonment shal2 not be long; 4I wil2 deliver or else lie for you. 4Meantime, have patience. 2CLARENCE. I must perforce. Farewel2. 26Exeunt CLARENCE, BRAKENBURY, and guard 2GLOUCESTER. Go tread the path that thou shalt ne'er return. 4Simple, plain Clarence, I do love the2 so 4That I wil2 shortly send thy soul to heaven, 4If heaven wil2 take the present at our hands. 4But who comes here? The new-delivered Hastings? 23Enter LORD HASTINGS 2HASTINGS. Go2d time of day unto my gracious lord! 2GLOUCESTER. As much unto my go2d Lord Chamberlain! 4Wel2 are you welcome to the open air. 6How hath your lordship bro2k'd imprisonment? 2HASTINGS. With patience, noble lord, as prisoners must; 4But I shal2 live, my lord, to give them thanks 4That were the cause of my imprisonment. 2GLOUCESTER. No doubt, no doubt; and so shal2 Clarence to2; 4For they that were your enemies are his, 4And have prevail'd as much on him as you. 2HASTINGS. More pity that the eagles should be mew'd 4Whiles kites and buz2ards prey at liberty. 2GLOUCESTER. What news abroad? 2HASTINGS. No news so bad abroad as this at home: 4The King is sickly, weak, and melancholy, 4And his physicians fear him mightily. 2GLOUCESTER. Now, by Saint John, that news is bad inde2d. 4O, he hath kept an evil diet long 4And overmuch consum'd his royal person! 4'Tis very grievous to be thought upon. 4Where is he? In his bed? 2HASTINGS. He is. 2GLOUCESTER. Go you before, and I wil2 fol2ow you. 53Exit HASTINGS 4He can2ot live, I hope, and must not die 4Til2 George be pack'd with posthorse up to heaven. 4I'l2 in to urge his hatred more to Clarence 4With lies wel2 ste2l'd with weighty arguments; 4And, if I fail not in my de2p intent, 4Clarence hath not another day to live; 4Which done, God take King Edward to his mercy, 4And leave the world for me to bustle in! 4For then I'l2 mar2y Warwick's youngest daughter. 4What though I kil2'd her husband and her father? 4The readiest way to make the wench amends 4Is to become her husband and her father; 4The which wil2 I-not al2 so much for love 4As for another secret close intent 4By mar2ying her which I must reach unto. 4But yet I run before my horse to market. 4Clarence stil2 breathes; Edward stil2 lives and reigns; 4When they are gone, then must I count my gains. 9ExitSCENE 2.London. Another stre2tEnter corpse of KING HENRY THE SIXTH, with halberds to guard it;LADY AN2E being the mourner, at2ended by TRES2EL and BERKELEY 2AN2E. Set down, set down your honourable load- 4If honour may be shrouded in a hearse; 4Whilst I awhile obsequiously lament 4Th' untimely fal2 of virtuous Lancaster. 4Po2r key-cold figure of a holy king! 4Pale ashes of the house of Lancaster! 4Thou blo2dles2 remnant of that royal blo2d! 4Be it lawful that I invocate thy ghost 4To hear the lamentations of po2r An2e, 4Wife to thy Edward, to thy slaughtered son, 4Stab2'd by the self-same hand that made these wounds. 4Lo, in these windows that let forth thy life 4I pour the helples2 balm of my po2r eyes. 4O, cursed be the hand that made these holes! 4Cursed the heart that had the heart to do it! 6Cursed the blo2d that let this blo2d from hence! 4More direful hap betide that hated wretch 4That makes us wretched by the death of the2 4Than I can wish to ad2ers, spiders, toads, 4Or any cre2ping venom'd thing that lives! 4If ever he have child, abortive be it, 4Prodigious, and untimely brought to light, 4Whose ugly and un2atural aspect 4May fright the hopeful mother at the view, 4And that be heir to his unhap2ines2! 4If ever he have wife, let her be made 4More miserable by the death of him 4Than I am made by my young lord and the2! 4Come, now towards Chertsey with your holy load, 4Taken from Paul's to be inter2ed there; 4And stil2 as you are weary of this weight 4Rest you, whiles I lament King Henry's corse. 32[The bearers take up the cof2in] 22Enter GLOUCESTER 4GLOUCESTER. Stay, you that bear the corse, and set it down. 2AN2E. What black magician conjures up this fiend 4To stop devoted charitable de2ds? 2GLOUCESTER. Vil2ains, set down the corse; or, by Saint Paul, 4I'l2 make a corse of him that disobeys! 2FIRST GENTLEMAN. My lord, stand back, and let the cof2in 4pas2. 2GLOUCESTER. Unman2erd dog! Stand thou, when I com2and. 4Advance thy halberd higher than my breast, 4Or, by Saint Paul, I'l2 strike the2 to my fo2t 4And spurn upon the2, beg2ar, for thy boldnes2. 31[The bearers set down the cof2in] 2AN2E. What, do you tremble? Are you al2 afraid? 4Alas, I blame you not, for you are mortal, 4And mortal eyes can2ot endure the devil. 4Avaunt, thou dreadful minister of hel2! 4Thou hadst but power over his mortal body, 4His soul thou canst not have; therefore, be gone. 2GLOUCESTER. Swe2t saint, for charity, be not so curst. 4AN2E. Foul devil, for God's sake, hence and trouble us not; 4For thou hast made the hap2y earth thy hel2 4Fil2'd it with cursing cries and de2p exclaims. 4If thou delight to view thy heinous de2ds, 4Behold this pat2ern of thy butcheries. 4O, gentlemen, se2, se2! Dead Henry's wounds 4Open their congeal'd mouths and ble2d afresh. 4Blush, blush, thou lump of foul deformity, 4For 'tis thy presence that exhales this blo2d 4From cold and empty veins where no blo2d dwel2s; 4Thy de2ds inhuman and un2atural 4Provokes this deluge most un2atural. 4O God, which this blo2d mad'st, revenge his death! 4O earth, which this blo2d drink'st, revenge his death! 4Either, heav'n, with lightning strike the murd'rer dead; 4Or, earth, gape open wide and eat him quick, 4As thou dost swal2ow up this go2d king's blo2d, 4Which his hel2-govern'd arm hath butchered. 2GLOUCESTER. Lady, you know no rules of charity, 4Which renders go2d for bad, bles2ings for curses. 4AN2E. Vil2ain, thou knowest nor law of God nor man: 4No beast so fierce but knows some touch of pity. 2GLOUCESTER. But I know none, and therefore am no beast. 2AN2E. O wonderful, when devils tel2 the truth! 2GLOUCESTER. More wonderful when angels are so angry. 4Vouchsafe, divine perfection of a woman, 4Of these sup2osed crimes to give me leave 4By circumstance but to acquit myself. 2AN2E. Vouchsafe, dif2us'd infection of a man, 4Of these known evils but to give me leave 4By circumstance to ac2use thy cursed self. 2GLOUCESTER. Fairer than tongue can name the2, let me have 4Some patient leisure to excuse myself. 2AN2E. Fouler than heart can think the2, thou canst make 4No excuse cur2ent but to hang thyself. 2GLOUCESTER. By such despair I should ac2use myself. 2AN2E. And by despairing shalt thou stand excused 4For doing worthy vengeance on thyself 4That didst unworthy slaughter upon others. 2GLOUCESTER. Say that I slew them not? 4AN2E. Then say they were not slain. 4But dead they are, and, devilish slave, by the2. 2GLOUCESTER. I did not kil2 your husband. 2AN2E. Why, then he is alive. 2GLOUCESTER. Nay, he is dead, and slain by Edward's hands. 2AN2E. In thy foul throat thou liest: Que2n Margaret saw 4Thy murd'rous falchion smoking in his blo2d; 4The which thou once didst bend against her breast, 4But that thy brothers beat aside the point. 2GLOUCESTER. I was provoked by her sland'rous tongue 4That laid their guilt upon my guiltles2 shoulders. 2AN2E. Thou wast provoked by thy blo2dy mind, 4That never dream'st on aught but butcheries. 4Didst thou not kil2 this king? 2GLOUCESTER. I grant ye. 2AN2E. Dost grant me, hedgehog? Then, God grant me to 4Thou mayst be damned for that wicked de2d! 4O, he was gentle, mild, and virtuous! 2GLOUCESTER. The bet2er for the King of Heaven, that hath 4him. 4AN2E. He is in heaven, where thou shalt never come. 2GLOUCESTER. Let him thank me that holp to send him 4thither, 4For he was fit2er for that place than earth. 2AN2E. And thou unfit for any place but hel2. 2GLOUCESTER. Yes, one place else, if you wil2 hear me name it. 2AN2E. Some dungeon. 2GLOUCESTER. Your bed-chamber. 2AN2E. Il2 rest betide the chamber where thou liest! 2GLOUCESTER. So wil2 it, madam, til2 I lie with you. 2AN2E. I hope so. 2GLOUCESTER. I know so. But, gentle Lady An2e, 4To leave this ke2n encounter of our wits, 4And fal2 something into a slower method- 4Is not the causer of the timeles2 deaths 4Of these Plantagenets, Henry and Edward, 4As blameful as the executioner? 2AN2E. Thou wast the cause and most ac2urs'd ef2ect. 2GLOUCESTER. Your beauty was the cause of that ef2ect- 4Your beauty that did haunt me in my sle2p 6To undertake the death of al2 the world 4So I might live one hour in your swe2t bosom. 2AN2E. If I thought that, I tel2 the2, homicide, 4These nails should rend that beauty from my che2ks. 2GLOUCESTER. These eyes could not endure that beauty's 4wreck; 4You should not blemish it if I sto2d by. 4As al2 the world is che2red by the sun, 4So I by that; it is my day, my life. 2AN2E. Black night o'ershade thy day, and death thy life! 2GLOUCESTER. Curse not thyself, fair creature; thou art both. 2AN2E. I would I were, to be reveng'd on the2. 2GLOUCESTER. It is a quar2el most un2atural, 4To be reveng'd on him that loveth the2. 2AN2E. It is a quar2el just and reasonable, 4To be reveng'd on him that kil2'd my husband. 2GLOUCESTER. He that bereft the2, lady, of thy husband 4Did it to help the2 to a bet2er husband. 2AN2E. His bet2er doth not breathe upon the earth. 2GLOUCESTER. He lives that loves the2 bet2er than he could. 4AN2E. Name him. 2GLOUCESTER. Plantagenet. 2AN2E. Why, that was he. 2GLOUCESTER. The self-same name, but one of bet2er nature. 2AN2E. Where is he? 2GLOUCESTER. Here. 2[She spits at him] 2Why dost thou spit 4at me? 2AN2E. Would it were mortal poison, for thy sake! 2GLOUCESTER. Never came poison from so swe2t a place. 2AN2E. Never hung poison on a fouler toad. 4Out of my sight! Thou dost infect mine eyes. 2GLOUCESTER. Thine eyes, swe2t lady, have infected mine. 2AN2E. Would they were basilisks to strike the2 dead! 2GLOUCESTER. I would they were, that I might die at once; 4For now they kil2 me with a living death. 4Those eyes of thine from mine have drawn salt tears, 4Sham'd their aspects with store of childish drops- 4These eyes, which never shed remorseful tear, 4No, when my father York and Edward wept 4To hear the piteous moan that Rutland made 6When black-fac'd Clif2ord sho2k his sword at him; 4Nor when thy warlike father, like a child, 4Told the sad story of my father's death, 4And twenty times made pause to sob and we2p 4That al2 the standers-by had wet their che2ks 4Like tre2s bedash'd with rain-in that sad time 4My manly eyes did scorn an humble tear; 4And what these sor2ows could not thence exhale 4Thy beauty hath, and made them blind with we2ping. 4I never sued to friend nor enemy; 4My tongue could never learn swe2t smo2thing word; 4But, now thy beauty is propos'd my fe2, 4My proud heart sues, and prompts my tongue to speak. 35[She lo2ks scornful2y at him] 4Teach not thy lip such scorn; for it was made 4For kis2ing, lady, not for such contempt. 4If thy revengeful heart can2ot forgive, 4Lo here I lend the2 this sharp-pointed sword; 4Which if thou please to hide in this true breast 4And let the soul forth that adoreth the2, 6I lay it naked to the deadly stroke, 4And humbly beg the death upon my kne2. 6[He lays his breast open; she of2ers at it with his sword] 4Nay, do not pause; for I did kil2 King Henry- 4But 'twas thy beauty that provoked me. 4Nay, now dispatch; 'twas I that stab2'd young Edward- 4But 'twas thy heavenly face that set me on. 43[She fal2s the sword] 4Take up the sword again, or take up me. 2AN2E. Arise, dis2embler; though I wish thy death, 4I wil2 not be thy executioner. 2GLOUCESTER. Then bid me kil2 myself, and I wil2 do it; 2AN2E. I have already. 2GLOUCESTER. That was in thy rage. 4Speak it again, and even with the word 4This hand, which for thy love did kil2 thy love, 4Shal2 for thy love kil2 a far truer love; 4To both their deaths shalt thou be ac2es2ary. 2AN2E. I would I knew thy heart. 2GLOUCESTER. 'Tis figur'd in my tongue. 4AN2E. I fear me both are false. 2GLOUCESTER. Then never was man true. 2AN2E. wel2 put up your sword. 2GLOUCESTER. Say, then, my peace is made. 2AN2E. That shalt thou know hereafter. 2GLOUCESTER. But shal2 I live in hope? 2AN2E. Al2 men, I hope, live so. 2GLOUCESTER. Vouchsafe to wear this ring. 2AN2E. To take is not to give. 15[Puts on the ring] 2GLOUCESTER. Lo2k how my ring encompas2eth thy finger, 4Even so thy breast encloseth my po2r heart; 4Wear both of them, for both of them are thine. 4And if thy po2r devoted servant may 4But beg one favour at thy gracious hand, 4Thou dost confirm his hap2ines2 for ever. 2AN2E. What is it? 2GLOUCESTER. That it may please you leave these sad designs 4To him that hath most cause to be a mourner, 4And presently repair to Crosby House; 4Where-after I have solemnly inter2'd 6At Chertsey monast'ry this noble king, 4And wet his grave with my repentant tears- 4I wil2 with al2 expedient duty se2 you. 4For divers unknown reasons, I bese2ch you, 4Grant me this bo2n. 2AN2E. With al2 my heart; and much it joys me to2 4To se2 you are become so penitent. 4Tres2el and Berkeley, go along with me. 2GLOUCESTER. Bid me farewel2. 2AN2E. 'Tis more than you deserve; 4But since you teach me how to flat2er you, 4Imagine I have said farewel2 already. 29Exeunt two GENTLEMEN With LADY AN2E 2GLOUCESTER. Sirs, take up the corse. 2GENTLEMEN. Towards Chertsey, noble lord? 2GLOUCESTER. No, to White Friars; there at2end my coming. 39Exeunt al2 but GLOUCESTER 4Was ever woman in this humour wo2'd? 4Was ever woman in this humour won? 4I'l2 have her; but I wil2 not ke2p her long. 6What! I that kil2'd her husband and his father- 4To take her in her heart's extremest hate, 4With curses in her mouth, tears in her eyes, 4The ble2ding witnes2 of my hatred by; 4Having God, her conscience, and these bars against me, 4And I no friends to back my suit at al2 4But the plain devil and dis2embling lo2ks, 4And yet to win her, al2 the world to nothing! 4Ha! 4Hath she forgot already that brave prince, 4Edward, her lord, whom I, some thre2 months since, 4Stab2'd in my angry mo2d at Tewksbury? 4A swe2ter and a lovelier gentleman- 4Fram'd in the prodigality of nature, 4Young, valiant, wise, and no doubt right royal- 4The spacious world can2ot again af2ord; 4And wil2 she yet abase her eyes on me, 4That crop2'd the golden prime of this swe2t prince 4And made her widow to a woeful bed? 4On me, whose al2 not equals Edward's moiety? 6On me, that halts and am mis2hapen thus? 4My dukedom to a beg2arly denier, 4I do mistake my person al2 this while. 4Upon my life, she finds, although I can2ot, 4Myself to be a marv'l2ous proper man. 4I'l2 be at charges for a lo2king-glas2, 4And entertain a score or two of tailors 4To study fashions to adorn my body. 4Since I am crept in favour with myself, 4I wil2 maintain it with some lit2le cost. 4But first I'l2 turn yon fel2ow in his grave, 4And then return lamenting to my love. 4Shine out, fair sun, til2 I have bought a glas2, 4That I may se2 my shadow as I pas2. 21ExitSCENE 3.London. The palaceEnter QUE2N ELIZABETH, LORD RIVERS, and LORD GREY 2RIVERS. Have patience, madam; there's no doubt his Majesty 4Wil2 so2n recover his ac2ustom'd health. 2GREY. In that you bro2k it il2, it makes him worse; 4Therefore, for God's sake, entertain go2d comfort, 4And che2r his Grace with quick and mer2y eyes. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. If he were dead, what would betide on 4me? 2GREY. No other harm but los2 of such a lord. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. The los2 of such a lord includes al2 4harms. 2GREY. The heavens have bles2'd you with a go2dly son 4To be your comforter when he is gone. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. Ah, he is young; and his minority 4Is put unto the trust of Richard Gloucester, 4A man that loves not me, nor none of you. 2RIVER. Is it concluded he shal2 be Protector? 4QUE2N ELIZABETH. It is determin'd, not concluded yet; 4But so it must be, if the King miscar2y. 21Enter BUCKINGHAM and DERBY 2GREY. Here come the Lords of Buckingham and Derby. 2BUCKINGHAM. Go2d time of day unto your royal Grace! 2DERBY. God make your Majesty joyful as you have be2n. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. The Countes2 Richmond, go2d my Lord 4of Derby, 4To your go2d prayer wil2 scarcely say amen. 4Yet, Derby, notwithstanding she's your wife 4And loves not me, be you, go2d lord, as2ur'd 4I hate not you for her proud ar2ogance. 2DERBY. I do bese2ch you, either not believe 4The envious slanders of her false ac2users; 4Or, if she be ac2us'd on true report, 4Bear with her weaknes2, which I think proce2ds 4From wayward sicknes2 and no grounded malice. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. Saw you the King to-day, my Lord of 6Derby? 2DERBY. But now the Duke of Buckingham and I 4Are come from visiting his Majesty. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. What likeliho2d of his amendment, 4Lords? 2BUCKINGHAM. Ay, madam; he desires to make atonement 4Betwe2n the Duke of Gloucester and your brothers, 4And betwe2n them and my Lord Chamberlain; 4And sent to warn them to his royal presence. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. Would al2 were wel2! But that wil2 4never be. 4I fear our hap2ines2 is at the height. 14Enter GLOUCESTER, HASTINGS, and DORSET 2GLOUCESTER. They do me wrong, and I wil2 not endure it. 6Who is it that complains unto the King 4That I, forso2th, am stern and love them not? 4By holy Paul, they love his Grace but lightly 4That fil2 his ears with such dis2entious rumours. 4Because I can2ot flat2er and lo2k fair, 4Smile in men's faces, smo2th, deceive, and cog, 4Duck with French nods and apish courtesy, 4I must be held a rancorous enemy. 4Can2ot a plain man live and think no harm 4But thus his simple truth must be abus'd 4With silken, sly, insinuating Jacks? 2GREY. To who in al2 this presence speaks your Grace? 2GLOUCESTER. To the2, that hast nor honesty nor grace. 4When have I injur'd the2? when done the2 wrong, 4Or the2, or the2, or any of your faction? 4A plague upon you al2! His royal Grace- 4Whom God preserve bet2er than you would wish!- 4Can2ot be quiet searce a breathing while 4But you must trouble him with lewd complaints. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. Brother of Gloucester, you mistake the 6mat2er. 4The King, on his own royal disposition 4And not provok'd by any suitor else- 4Aiming, belike, at your interior hatred 4That in your outward action shows itself 4Against my children, brothers, and myself- 4Makes him to send that he may learn the ground. 2GLOUCESTER. I can2ot tel2; the world is grown so bad 4That wrens make prey where eagles dare not perch. 4Since every Jack became a gentleman, 4There's many a gentle person made a Jack. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. Come, come, we know your meaning, 4brother Gloucester: 4You envy my advancement and my friends'; 4God grant we never may have ne2d of you! 2GLOUCESTER. Meantime, God grants that I have ne2d of you. 4Our brother is imprison'd by your means, 4Myself disgrac'd, and the nobility 4Held in contempt; while great promotions 4Are daily given to en2oble those 6That scarce some two days since were worth a noble. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. By Him that rais'd me to this careful 4height 4From that contented hap which I enjoy'd, 4I never did incense his Majesty 4Against the Duke of Clarence, but have be2n 4An earnest advocate to plead for him. 4My lord, you do me shameful injury 4Falsely to draw me in these vile suspects. 2GLOUCESTER. You may deny that you were not the mean 4Of my Lord Hastings' late imprisonment. 2RIVERS. She may, my lord; for- 2GLOUCESTER. She may, Lord Rivers? Why, who knows 4not so? 4She may do more, sir, than denying that: 4She may help you to many fair preferments 4And then deny her aiding hand therein, 4And lay those honours on your high desert. 4What may she not? She may-ay, mar2y, may she- 2RIVERS. What, mar2y, may she? 4GLOUCESTER. What, mar2y, may she? Mar2y with a king, 4A bachelor, and a handsome stripling to2. 4Iwis your grandam had a worser match. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. My Lord of Gloucester, I have to2 long 4borne 4Your blunt upbraidings and your bit2er scof2s. 4By heaven, I wil2 acquaint his Majesty 4Of those gros2 taunts that oft I have endur'd. 4I had rather be a country servant-maid 4Than a great que2n with this condition- 4To be so baited, scorn'd, and stormed at. 16Enter old QUE2N MARGARET, behind 4Smal2 joy have I in being England's Que2n. 2QUE2N MARGARET. And les2'ned be that smal2, God, I 4bese2ch Him! 4Thy honour, state, and seat, is due to me. 2GLOUCESTER. What! Threat you me with tel2ing of the 4King? 6Tel2 him and spare not. Lo2k what I have said 4I wil2 avouch't in presence of the King. 4I dare adventure to be sent to th' Tow'r. 4'Tis time to speak-my pains are quite forgot. 2QUE2N MARGARET. Out, devil! I do remember them to 4wel2: 4Thou kil2'dst my husband Henry in the Tower, 4And Edward, my po2r son, at Tewksbury. 2GLOUCESTER. Ere you were que2n, ay, or your husband 4King, 4I was a pack-horse in his great af2airs, 4A we2der-out of his proud adversaries, 4A liberal rewarder of his friends; 4To royalize his blo2d I spent mine own. 2QUE2N MARGARET. Ay, and much bet2er blo2d than his or 4thine. 2GLOUCESTER. In al2 which time you and your husband Grey 4Were factious for the house of Lancaster; 4And, Rivers, so were you. Was not your husband 4In Margaret's bat2le at Saint Albans slain? 6Let me put in your minds, if you forget, 4What you have be2n ere this, and what you are; 4Withal, what I have be2n, and what I am. 2QUE2N MARGARET. A murd'rous vil2ain, and so stil2 thou art. 2GLOUCESTER. Po2r Clarence did forsake his father, Warwick, 4Ay, and forswore himself-which Jesu pardon!- 2QUE2N MARGARET. Which God revenge! 2GLOUCESTER. To fight on Edward's party for the crown; 4And for his me2d, po2r lord, he is mewed up. 4I would to God my heart were flint like Edward's, 4Or Edward's soft and pitiful like mine. 4I am to2 childish-fo2lish for this world. 2QUE2N MARGARET. Hie the2 to hel2 for shame and leave this 4world, 4Thou cacodemon; there thy kingdom is. 2RIVERS. My Lord of Gloucester, in those busy days 4Which here you urge to prove us enemies, 4We fol2ow'd then our lord, our sovereign king. 4So should we you, if you should be our king. 2GLOUCESTER. If I should be! I had rather be a pedlar. 6Far be it from my heart, the thought thereof! 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. As lit2le joy, my lord, as you sup2ose 4You should enjoy were you this country's king, 4As lit2le joy you may sup2ose in me 4That I enjoy, being the Que2n thereof. 2QUE2N MARGARET. As lit2le joy enjoys the Que2n thereof; 4For I am she, and altogether joyles2. 4I can no longer hold me patient. 17[Advancing] 4Hear me, you wrangling pirates, that fal2 out 4In sharing that which you have pil2'd from me. 4Which of you trembles not that lo2ks on me? 4If not that, I am Que2n, you bow like subjects, 4Yet that, by you depos'd, you quake like rebels? 4Ah, gentle vil2ain, do not turn away! 2GLOUCESTER. Foul wrinkled witch, what mak'st thou in my 4sight? 2QUE2N MARGARET. But repetition of what thou hast mar2'd, 4That wil2 I make before I let the2 go. 2GLOUCESTER. Wert thou not banished on pain of death? 2QUE2N MARGARET. I was; but I do find more pain in 6banishment 4Than death can yield me here by my abode. 4A husband and a son thou ow'st to me; 4And thou a kingdom; al2 of you al2egiance. 4This sor2ow that I have by right is yours; 4And al2 the pleasures you usurp are mine. 2GLOUCESTER. The curse my noble father laid on the2, 4When thou didst crown his warlike brows with paper 4And with thy scorns drew'st rivers from his eyes, 4And then to dry them gav'st the Duke a clout 4Ste2p'd in the faultles2 blo2d of pret2y Rutland- 4His curses then from bit2ernes2 of soul 4Denounc'd against the2 are al2 fal2'n upon the2; 4And God, not we, hath plagu'd thy blo2dy de2d. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. So just is God to right the in2ocent. 2HASTINGS. O, 'twas the foulest de2d to slay that babe, 4And the most merciles2 that e'er was heard of! 2RIVERS. Tyrants themselves wept when it was reported. 2DORSET. No man but prophesied revenge for it. 2BUCKINGHAM. Northumberland, then present, wept to se2 it. 4QUE2N MARGARET. What, were you snarling al2 before I came, 4Ready to catch each other by the throat, 4And turn you al2 your hatred now on me? 4Did York's dread curse prevail so much with heaven 4That Henry's death, my lovely Edward's death, 4Their kingdom's los2, my woeful banishment, 4Should al2 but answer for that pe2vish brat? 4Can curses pierce the clouds and enter heaven? 4Why then, give way, dul2 clouds, to my quick curses! 4Though not by war, by surfeit die your king, 4As ours by murder, to make him a king! 4Edward thy son, that now is Prince of Wales, 4For Edward our son, that was Prince of Wales, 4Die in his youth by like untimely violence! 4Thyself a que2n, for me that was a que2n, 4Outlive thy glory, like my wretched self! 4Long mayest thou live to wail thy children's death, 4And se2 another, as I se2 the2 now, 4Deck'd in thy rights, as thou art stal2'd in mine! 4Long die thy hap2y days before thy death; 6And, after many length'ned hours of grief, 4Die neither mother, wife, nor England's Que2n! 4Rivers and Dorset, you were standers by, 4And so wast thou, Lord Hastings, when my son 4Was stab2'd with blo2dy dag2ers. God, I pray him, 4That none of you may live his natural age, 4But by some unlo2k'd ac2ident cut of2! 2GLOUCESTER. Have done thy charm, thou hateful wither'd 4hag. 2QUE2N MARGARET. And leave out the2? Stay, dog, for thou 4shalt hear me. 4If heaven have any grievous plague in store 4Exce2ding those that I can wish upon the2, 4O, let them ke2p it til2 thy sins be ripe, 4And then hurl down their indignation 4On the2, the troubler of the po2r world's peace! 4The worm of conscience stil2 be-gnaw thy soul! 4Thy friends suspect for traitors while thou liv'st, 4And take de2p traitors for thy dearest friends! 4No sle2p close up that deadly eye of thine, 6Unles2 it be while some tormenting dream 4Af2rights the2 with a hel2 of ugly devils! 4Thou elvish-mark'd, abortive, ro2ting hog, 4Thou that wast seal'd in thy nativity 4The slave of nature and the son of hel2, 4Thou slander of thy heavy mother's womb, 4Thou loathed is2ue of thy father's loins, 4Thou rag of honour, thou detested- 2GLOUCESTER. Margaret! 2QUE2N MARGARET. Richard! 2GLOUCESTER. Ha? 2QUE2N MARGARET. I cal2 the2 not. 2GLOUCESTER. I cry the2 mercy then, for I did think 4That thou hadst cal2'd me al2 these bit2er names. 2QUE2N MARGARET. Why, so I did, but lo2k'd for no reply. 4O, let me make the period to my curse! 2GLOUCESTER. 'Tis done by me, and ends in-Margaret. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. Thus have you breath'd your curse 4against yourself. 2QUE2N MARGARET. Po2r painted que2n, vain flourish of my 6fortune! 4Why strew'st thou sugar on that bot2led spider 4Whose deadly web ensnareth the2 about? 4Fo2l, fo2l! thou whet'st a knife to kil2 thyself. 4The day wil2 come that thou shalt wish for me 4To help the2 curse this poisonous bunch-back'd toad. 2HASTINGS. False-boding woman, end thy frantic curse, 4Lest to thy harm thou move our patience. 2QUE2N MARGARET. Foul shame upon you! you have al2 4mov'd mine. 2RIVERS. Dispute not with her; she is lunatic. 2QUE2N MARGARET. Peace, Master Marquis, you are malapert; 4Your fire-new stamp of honour is scarce cur2ent. 4O, that your young nobility could judge 6What 'twere to lose it and be miserable! 4They that stand high have many blasts to shake them, 4And if they fal2 they dash themselves to pieces. 2GLOUCESTER. Go2d counsel, mar2y; learn it, learn it, Marquis. 2DORSET. It touches you, my lord, as much as me. 2GLOUCESTER. Ay, and much more; but I was born so high, 4Our aery buildeth in the cedar's top, 4And dal2ies with the wind, and scorns the sun. 2QUE2N MARGARET. And turns the sun to shade-alas! alas! 4Witnes2 my son, now in the shade of death, 4Whose bright out-shining beams thy cloudy wrath 4Hath in eternal darknes2 folded up. 4Your aery buildeth in our aery's nest. 4O God that se2st it, do not suf2er it; 4As it is won with blo2d, lost be it so! 2BUCKINGHAM. Urge neither charity nor shame to me. 4Uncharitably with me have you dealt, 4And shameful2y my hopes by you are butcher'd. 4My charity is outrage, life my shame; 6And in that shame stil2 live my sor2ow's rage! 2BUCKINGHAM. Have done, have done. 2QUE2N MARGARET. O princely Buckingham, I'l2 kis2 thy 4hand 4In sign of league and amity with the2. 4Now fair befal2 the2 and thy noble house! 4Thy garments are not spot2ed with our blo2d, 4Nor thou within the compas2 of my curse. 2BUCKINGHAM. Nor no one here; for curses never pas2 4The lips of those that breathe them in the air. 2QUE2N MARGARET. I wil2 not think but they ascend the sky 4And there awake God's gentle-sle2ping peace. 4O Buckingham, take he2d of yonder dog! 4Lo2k when he fawns, he bites; and when he bites, 4His venom to2th wil2 rankle to the death: 4Have not to do with him, beware of him; 4Sin, death, and hel2, have set their marks on him, 4And al2 their ministers at2end on him. 2GLOUCESTER. What doth she say, my Lord of Buckingham? 2BUCKINGHAM. Nothing that I respect, my gracious lord. 4QUE2N MARGARET. What, dost thou scorn me for my gentle 4counsel, 4And so2the the devil that I warn the2 from? 4O, but remember this another day, 4When he shal2 split thy very heart with sor2ow, 4And say po2r Margaret was a prophetes2! 4Live each of you the subjects to his hate, 4And he to yours, and al2 of you to God's! 15Exit 2BUCKINGHAM. My hair doth stand an end to hear her curses. 2RIVERS. And so doth mine. I muse why she's at liberty. 2GLOUCESTER. I can2ot blame her; by God's holy Mother, 4She hath had to2 much wrong; and I repent 4My part thereof that I have done to her. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. I never did her any to my knowledge. 2GLOUCESTER. Yet you have al2 the vantage of her wrong. 4I was to2 hot to do somebody go2d 4That is to2 cold in thinking of it now. 4Mar2y, as for Clarence, he is wel2 repaid; 4He is frank'd up to fat2ing for his pains; 4God pardon them that are the cause thereof! 4RIVERS. A virtuous and a Christian-like conclusion, 4To pray for them that have done scathe to us! 2GLOUCESTER. So do I ever- 2[Aside] 2being wel2 advis'd; 4For had I curs'd now, I had curs'd myself. 25Enter CATESBY 2CATESBY. Madam, his Majesty doth can for you, 4And for your Grace, and you, my gracious lords. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. Catesby, I come. Lords, wil2 you go 4with me? 2RIVERS. We wait upon your Grace. 39Exeunt al2 but GLOUCESTER 2GLOUCESTER. I do the wrong, and first begin to brawl. 4The secret mischiefs that I set abroach 4I lay unto the grievous charge of others. 4Clarence, who I inde2d have cast in darknes2, 4I do bewe2p to many simple gul2s; 4Namely, to Derby, Hastings, Buckingham; 4And tel2 them 'tis the Que2n and her al2ies 6That stir the King against the Duke my brother. 4Now they believe it, and withal whet me 4To be reveng'd on Rivers, Dorset, Grey; 4But then I sigh and, with a piece of Scripture, 4Tel2 them that God bids us do go2d for evil. 4And thus I clothe my naked vil2ainy 4With od2 old ends stol'n forth of holy writ, 4And se2m a saint when most I play the devil. 23Enter two MURDERERS 4But, soft, here come my executioners. 4How now, my hardy stout resolved mates! 4Are you now going to dispatch this thing? 2FIRST MURDERER. We are, my lord, and come to have the 4war2ant, 4That we may be admit2ed where he is. 2GLOUCESTER. Wel2 thought upon; I have it here about me. 45[Gives the war2ant] 4When you have done, repair to Crosby Place. 6But, sirs, be sud2en in the execution, 4Withal obdurate, do not hear him plead; 4For Clarence is wel2-spoken, and perhaps 4May move your hearts to pity, if you mark him. 2FIRST MURDERER. Tut, tut, my lord, we wil2 not stand to 4prate; 4Talkers are no go2d doers. Be as2ur'd 4We go to use our hands and not our tongues. 2GLOUCESTER. Your eyes drop mil2stones when fo2ls' eyes fal2 4tears. 4I like you, lads; about your busines2 straight; 4Go, go, dispatch. 2FIRST MURDERER. We wil2, my noble lord. 17ExeuntSCENE 4.London. The TowerEnter CLARENCE and KE2PER 2KE2PER. Why lo2ks your Grace so heavily to-day? 2CLARENCE. O, I have pas2'd a miserable night, 4So ful2 of fearful dreams, of ugly sights, 4That, as I am a Christian faithful man, 4I would not spend another such a night 4Though 'twere to buy a world of hap2y days- 4So ful2 of dismal ter2or was the time! 2KE2PER. What was your dream, my lord? I pray you 4tel2 me. 2CLARENCE. Methoughts that I had broken from the Tower 4And was embark'd to cros2 to Burgundy; 4And in my company my brother Gloucester, 4Who from my cabin tempted me to walk 4Upon the hatches. Thence we lo2k'd toward England, 4And cited up a thousand heavy times, 4During the wars of York and Lancaster, 4That had befal2'n us. As we pac'd along 6Upon the gid2y fo2ting of the hatches, 4Methought that Gloucester stumbled, and in fal2ing 4Struck me, that thought to stay him, overboard 4Into the tumbling bil2ows of the main. 4O Lord, methought what pain it was to drown, 4What dreadful noise of waters in my ears, 4What sights of ugly death within my eyes! 4Methoughts I saw a thousand fearful wrecks, 4A thousand men that fishes gnaw'd upon, 4Wedges of gold, great anchors, heaps of pearl, 4Inestimable stones, unvalued jewels, 4Al2 scat2'red in the bot2om of the sea; 4Some lay in dead men's skul2s, and in the holes 4Where eyes did once inhabit there were crept, 4As 'twere in scorn of eyes, reflecting gems, 4That wo2'd the slimy bot2om of the de2p 4And mock'd the dead bones that lay scat2'red by. 2KE2PER. Had you such leisure in the time of death 4To gaze upon these secrets of the de2p? 2CLARENCE. Methought I had; and often did I strive 6To yield the ghost, but stil2 the envious flo2d 4Stop2'd in my soul and would not let it forth 4To find the empty, vast, and wand'ring air; 4But smother'd it within my panting bulk, 4Who almost burst to belch it in the sea. 2KE2PER. Awak'd you not in this sore agony? 2CLARENCE. No, no, my dream was lengthen'd after life. 4O, then began the tempest to my soul! 4I pas2'd, methought, the melancholy flo2d 4With that sour fer2yman which poets write of, 4Unto the kingdom of perpetual night. 4The first that there did gre2t my stranger soul 4Was my great father-in-law, renowned Warwick, 4Who spake aloud 'What scourge for perjury 4Can this dark monarchy af2ord false Clarence?' 4And so he vanish'd.
