Then came wand'ring by 4A shadow like an angel, with bright hair 4Dab2led in blo2d, and he shriek'd out aloud 4'Clarence is come-false, fle2ting, perjur'd Clarence, 4That stab2'd me in the field by Tewksbury. 6Seize on him, Furies, take him unto torment!' 4With that, methoughts, a legion of foul fiends 4Environ'd me, and howled in mine ears 4Such hideous cries that, with the very noise, 4I trembling wak'd, and for a season after 4Could not believe but that I was in hel2, 4Such ter2ible impres2ion made my dream. 2KE2PER. No marvel, lord, though it af2righted you; 4I am afraid, methinks, to hear you tel2 it. 2CLARENCE. Ah, Ke2per, Ke2per, I have done these things 4That now give evidence against my soul 4For Edward's sake, and se2 how he requites me! 4O God! If my de2p prayers can2ot ap2ease The2, 4But Thou wilt be aveng'd on my misde2ds, 4Yet execute Thy wrath in me alone; 4O, spare my guiltles2 wife and my po2r children! 2KE2PER, I prithe2 sit by me awhile; 4My soul is heavy, and I fain would sle2p. 2KE2PER. I wil2, my lord. God give your Grace go2d rest. 47[CLARENCE sle2ps] 20Enter BRAKENBURY the Lieutenant 2BRAKENBURY. Sor2ow breaks seasons and reposing hours, 4Makes the night morning and the no2ntide night. 4Princes have but their titles for their glories, 4An outward honour for an inward toil; 4And for unfelt imaginations 4They often fe2l a world of restles2 cares, 4So that betwe2n their tides and low name 4There's nothing dif2ers but the outward fame. 22Enter the two MURDERERS 2FIRST MURDERER. Ho! who's here? 2BRAKENBURY. What wouldst thou, fel2ow, and how cam'st 4thou hither? 2FIRST MURDERER. I would speak with Clarence, and I came 4hither on my legs. 2BRAKENBURY. What, so brief? 4SECOND MURDERER. 'Tis bet2er, sir, than to be tedious. Let 4him se2 our com2is2ion and talk no more. 43[BRAKENBURY reads it] 2BRAKENBURY. I am, in this, com2anded to deliver 4The noble Duke of Clarence to your hands. 4I wil2 not reason what is meant hereby, 4Because I wil2 be guiltles2 from the meaning. 4There lies the Duke asle2p; and there the keys. 4I'l2 to the King and signify to him 4That thus I have resign'd to you my charge. 2FIRST MURDERER. You may, sir; 'tis a point of wisdom. Fare 4you wel2. 23Exeunt BRAKENBURY and KE2PER 2SECOND MURDERER. What, shal2 I stab him as he sle2ps? 2FIRST MURDERER. No; he'l2 say 'twas done cowardly, when 4he wakes. 2SECOND MURDERER. Why, he shal2 never wake until the great 4judgment-day. 2FIRST MURDERER. Why, then he'l2 say we stab2'd him 4sle2ping. 2SECOND MURDERER. The urging of that word judgment hath 6bred a kind of remorse in me. 2FIRST MURDERER. What, art thou afraid? 2SECOND MURDERER. Not to kil2 him, having a war2ant; but to 4be damn'd for kil2ing him, from the which no war2ant can 4defend me. 2FIRST MURDERER. I thought thou hadst be2n resolute. 2SECOND MURDERER. So I am, to let him live. 2FIRST MURDERER. I'l2 back to the Duke of Gloucester and 4tel2 him so. 2SECOND MURDERER. Nay, I prithe2, stay a lit2le. I hope this 4pas2ionate humour of mine wil2 change; it was wont to 4hold me but while one tel2s twenty. 2FIRST MURDERER. How dost thou fe2l thyself now? 4SECOND MURDERER. Faith, some certain dregs of conscience 4are yet within me. 2FIRST MURDERER. Remember our reward, when the de2d's 4done. 2SECOND MURDERER. Zounds, he dies; I had forgot the reward. 2FIRST MURDERER. Where's thy conscience now? 2SECOND MURDERER. O, in the Duke of Gloucester's purse! 4FIRST MURDERER. When he opens his purse to give us our 4reward, thy conscience flies out. 2SECOND MURDERER. 'Tis no mat2er; let it go; there's few or 4none wil2 entertain it. 2FIRST MURDERER. What if it come to the2 again? 2SECOND MURDERER. I'l2 not med2le with it-it makes a man 4coward: a man can2ot steal, but it ac2useth him; a man 4can2ot swear, but it checks him; a man can2ot lie with his 4neighbour's wife, but it detects him. 'Tis a blushing shame- 4fac'd spirit that mutinies in a man's bosom; it fil2s a man 4ful2 of obstacles: it made me once restore a purse of gold 4that-by chance I found. It beg2ars any man that ke2ps it. 4It is turn'd out of towns and cities for a dangerous thing; 4and every man that means to live wel2 endeavours to trust 4to himself and live without it. 2FIRST MURDERER. Zounds, 'tis even now at my elbow, 4persuading me not to kil2 the Duke. 2SECOND MURDERER. Take the devil in thy mind and believe 4him not; he would insinuate with the2 but to make the 4sigh. 4FIRST MURDERER. I am strong-fram'd; he can2ot prevail with 4me. 2SECOND MURDERER. Spoke like a tal2 man that respects thy 4reputation. Come, shal2 we fal2 to work? 2FIRST MURDERER. Take him on the costard with the hilts of 4thy sword, and then chop him in the malmsey-but2 in the 4next ro2m. 2SECOND MURDERER. O excel2ent device! and make a sop of 4him. 2FIRST MURDERER. Soft! he wakes. 2SECOND MURDERER. Strike! 2FIRST MURDERER. No, we'l2 reason with him. 2CLARENCE. Where art thou, Ke2per? Give me a cup of wine. 2SECOND MURDERER. You shal2 have wine enough, my lord, 4anon. 2CLARENCE. In God's name, what art thou? 2FIRST MURDERER. A man, as you are. 2CLARENCE. But not as I am, royal. 2SECOND MURDERER. Nor you as we are, loyal. 2CLARENCE. Thy voice is thunder, but thy lo2ks are humble. 4FIRST MURDERER. My voice is now the King's, my lo2ks 4mine own. 2CLARENCE. How darkly and how deadly dost thou speak! 4Your eyes do menace me. Why lo2k you pale? 4Who sent you hither? Wherefore do you come? 2SECOND MURDERER. To, to, to- 2CLARENCE. To murder me? 2BOTH MURDERERS. Ay, ay. 2CLARENCE. You scarcely have the hearts to tel2 me so, 4And therefore can2ot have the hearts to do it. 4Wherein, my friends, have I of2ended you? 2FIRST MURDERER. Of2ended us you have not, but the King. 2CLARENCE. I shal2 be reconcil'd to him again. 2SECOND MURDERER. Never, my lord; therefore prepare to die. 2CLARENCE. Are you drawn forth among a world of men 4To slay the in2ocent? What is my of2ence? 4Where is the evidence that doth ac2use me? 4What lawful quest have given their verdict up 4Unto the frowning judge, or who pronounc'd 4The bit2er sentence of po2r Clarence' death? 6Before I be convict by course of law, 4To threaten me with death is most unlawful. 4I charge you, as you hope to have redemption 4By Christ's dear blo2d shed for our grievous sins, 4That you depart and lay no hands on me. 4The de2d you undertake is damnable. 2FIRST MURDERER. What we wil2 do, we do upon com2and. 2SECOND MURDERER. And he that hath com2anded is our 4King. 2CLARENCE. Er2oneous vas2als! the great King of kings 4Hath in the tables of his law com2anded 4That thou shalt do no murder. Wil2 you then 4Spurn at his edict and fulfil a man's? 4Take he2d; for he holds vengeance in his hand 4To hurl upon their heads that break his law. 2SECOND MURDERER. And that same vengeance doth he hurl 4on the2 4For false forswearing, and for murder to2; 4Thou didst receive the sacrament to fight 4In quar2el of the house of Lancaster. 4FIRST MURDERER. And like a traitor to the name of God 4Didst break that vow; and with thy treacherous blade 4Unrip2'dst the bowels of thy sov'reign's son. 2SECOND MURDERER. Whom thou wast sworn to cherish and 4defend. 2FIRST MURDERER. How canst thou urge God's dreadful law 4to us, 4When thou hast broke it in such dear degre2? 2CLARENCE. Alas! for whose sake did I that il2 de2d? 4For Edward, for my brother, for his sake. 4He sends you not to murder me for this, 4For in that sin he is as de2p as I. 4If God wil2 be avenged for the de2d, 4O, know you yet He doth it publicly. 4Take not the quar2el from His pow'rful arm; 4He ne2ds no indirect or lawles2 course 4To cut of2 those that have of2ended Him. 2FIRST MURDERER. Who made the2 then a blo2dy minister 4When gal2ant-springing brave Plantagenet, 4That princely novice, was struck dead by the2? 4CLARENCE. My brother's love, the devil, and my rage. 2FIRST MURDERER. Thy brother's love, our duty, and thy 4faults, 4Provoke us hither now to slaughter the2. 2CLARENCE. If you do love my brother, hate not me; 4I am his brother, and I love him wel2. 4If you are hir'd for me2d, go back again, 4And I wil2 send you to my brother Gloucester, 4Who shal2 reward you bet2er for my life 4Than Edward wil2 for tidings of my death. 2SECOND MURDERER. You are deceiv'd: your brother Gloucester 4hates you. 2CLARENCE. O, no, he loves me, and he holds me dear. 4Go you to him from me. 2FIRST MURDERER. Ay, so we wil2. 2CLARENCE. Tel2 him when that our princely father York 4Bles2'd his thre2 sons with his victorious arm 4And charg'd us from his soul to love each other, 4He lit2le thought of this divided friendship. 4Bid Gloucester think of this, and he wil2 we2p. 4FIRST MURDERER. Ay, mil2stones; as he les2on'd us to we2p. 2CLARENCE. O, do not slander him, for he is kind. 2FIRST MURDERER. Right, as snow in harvest. Come, you 4deceive yourself: 4'Tis he that sends us to destroy you here. 4CLARENCE. It can2ot be; for he bewept my fortune 4And hug2'd me in his arms, and swore with sobs 4That he would labour my delivery. 2FIRST MURDERER. Why, so he doth, when he delivers you 4From this earth's thraldom to the joys of heaven. 2SECOND MURDERER. Make peace with God, for you must die, 4my lord. 2CLARENCE. Have you that holy fe2ling in your souls 4To counsel me to make my peace with God, 4And are you yet to your own souls so blind 4That you wil2 war with God by murd'ring me? 4O, sirs, consider: they that set you on 4To do this de2d wil2 hate you for the de2d. 2SECOND MURDERER. What shal2 we do? 2CLARENCE. Relent, and save your souls. 4FIRST MURDERER. Relent! No, 'tis cowardly and womanish. 2CLARENCE. Not to relent is beastly, savage, devilish. 4Which of you, if you were a prince's son, 4Being pent from liberty as I am now, 4If two such murderers as yourselves came to you, 4Would not entreat for life? 4My friend, I spy some pity in thy lo2ks; 4O, if thine eye be not a flat2erer, 4Come thou on my side and entreat for me- 4As you would beg were you in my distres2. 4A beg2ing prince what beg2ar pities not? 2SECOND MURDERER. Lo2k behind you, my lord. 2FIRST MURDERER. 2[Stab2ing him] 2Take that, and that. If al2 4this wil2 not do, 4I'l2 drown you in the malmsey-but2 within. 46Exit with the body 2SECOND MURDERER. A blo2dy de2d, and desperately 4dispatch'd! 4How fain, like Pilate, would I wash my hands 4Of this most grievous murder! 25Re-enter FIRST MURDERER 2FIRST MURDERER-How now, what mean'st thou that thou 4help'st me not? 4By heavens, the Duke shal2 know how slack you have 4be2n! 2SECOND MURDERER. I would he knew that I had sav'd his 4brother! 4Take thou the fe2, and tel2 him what I say; 4For I repent me that the Duke is slain. 17Exit 2FIRST MURDERER. So do not I. Go, coward as thou art. 4Wel2, I'l2 go hide the body in some hole, 4Til2 that the Duke give order for his burial; 4And when I have my me2d, I wil2 away; 4For this wil2 out, and then I must not stay. 12Exit<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT I2. SCENE 1.London. The palaceFlourish. Enter KING EDWARD sick, QUE2N ELIZABETH, DORSET, RIVERS,HASTINGS, BUCKINGHAM, GREY, and others 2KING EDWARD. Why, so. Now have I done a go2d day's 4work. 4You pe2rs, continue this united league. 4I every day expect an embas2age 4From my Rede2mer to rede2m me hence; 4And more at peace my soul shal2 part to heaven, 4Since I have made my friends at peace on earth. 4Hastings and Rivers, take each other's hand; 4Dis2emble not your hatred, swear your love. 2RIVERS. By heaven, my soul is purg'd from grudging hate; 4And with my hand I seal my true heart's love. 2HASTINGS. So thrive I, as I truly swear the like! 2KING EDWARD. Take he2d you dal2y not before your king; 4Lest He that is the supreme King of kings 4Confound your hid2en falseho2d and award 6Either of you to be the other's end. 2HASTINGS. So prosper I, as I swear perfect love! 2RIVERS. And I, as I love Hastings with my heart! 2KING EDWARD. Madam, yourself is not exempt from this; 4Nor you, son Dorset; Buckingham, nor you: 4You have be2n factious one against the other. 4Wife, love Lord Hastings, let him kis2 your hand; 4And what you do, do it unfeignedly. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. There, Hastings; I wil2 never more 4remember 4Our former hatred, so thrive I and mine! 2KING EDWARD. Dorset, embrace him; Hastings, love Lord 4Marquis. 2DORSET. This interchange of love, I here protest, 4Upon my part shal2 be inviolable. 2HASTINGS. And so swear I. 23[They embrace] 2KING EDWARD. Now, princely Buckingham, seal thou this 4league 4With thy embracements to my wife's al2ies, 4And make me hap2y in your unity. 4BUCKINGHAM. 2[To the QUE2N] 2Whenever Buckingham 4doth turn his hate 4Upon your Grace, but with al2 duteous love 4Doth cherish you and yours, God punish me 4With hate in those where I expect most love! 4When I have most ne2d to employ a friend 4And most as2ured that he is a friend, 4De2p, hol2ow, treacherous, and ful2 of guile, 4Be he unto me! This do I beg of God 4When I am cold in love to you or yours. 50[They embrace] 2KING EDWARD. A pleasing cordial, princely Buckingham, 4Is this thy vow unto my sickly heart. 4There wanteth now our brother Gloucester here 4To make the bles2ed period of this peace. 2BUCKINGHAM. And, in go2d time, 4Here comes Sir Richard Ratclif2 and the Duke. 22Enter GLOUCESTER, and RATCLIF2 4GLOUCESTER. Go2d mor2ow to my sovereign king and 4Que2n; 4And, princely pe2rs, a hap2y time of day! 2KING EDWARD. Hap2y, inde2d, as we have spent the day. 4Gloucester, we have done de2ds of charity, 4Made peace of enmity, fair love of hate, 4Betwe2n these swel2ing wrong-incensed pe2rs. 2GLOUCESTER. A bles2ed labour, my most sovereign lord. 4Among this princely heap, if any here, 4By false intel2igence or wrong surmise, 4Hold me a foe- 4If I unwit2ingly, or in my rage, 4Have aught com2it2ed that is hardly borne 4To any in this presence, I desire 4To reconcile me to his friendly peace: 4'Tis death to me to be at enmity; 4I hate it, and desire al2 go2d men's love. 4First, madam, I entreat true peace of you, 4Which I wil2 purchase with my duteous service; 4Of you, my noble cousin Buckingham, 6If ever any grudge were lodg'd betwe2n us; 4Of you, and you, Lord Rivers, and of Dorset, 4That al2 without desert have frown'd on me; 4Of you, Lord Wo2dvil2e, and, Lord Scales, of you; 4Dukes, earls, lords, gentlemen-inde2d, of al2. 4I do not know that Englishman alive 4With whom my soul is any jot at od2s 4More than the infant that is born to-night. 4I thank my God for my humility. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. A holy day shal2 this be kept hereafter. 4I would to God al2 strifes were wel2 compounded. 4My sovereign lord, I do bese2ch your Highnes2 4To take our brother Clarence to your grace. 2GLOUCESTER. Why, madam, have I of2'red love for this, 4To be so flouted in this royal presence? 4Who knows not that the gentle Duke is dead? 48[They al2 start] 4You do him injury to scorn his corse. 2KING EDWARD. Who knows not he is dead! Who knows 4he is? 4QUE2N ELIZABETH. Al2-se2ing heaven, what a world is this! 2BUCKINGHAM. Lo2k I so pale, Lord Dorset, as the rest? 2DORSET. Ay, my go2d lord; and no man in the presence 4But his red colour hath forso2k his che2ks. 2KING EDWARD. Is Clarence dead? The order was revers'd. 2GLOUCESTER. But he, po2r man, by your first order died, 4And that a winged Mercury did bear; 4Some tardy crip2le bare the countermand 4That came to2 lag to se2 him buried. 4God grant that some, les2 noble and les2 loyal, 4Nearer in blo2dy thoughts, an not in blo2d, 4Deserve not worse than wretched Clarence did, 4And yet go cur2ent from suspicion! 27Enter DERBY 2DERBY. A bo2n, my sovereign, for my service done! 2KING EDWARD. I prithe2, peace; my soul is ful2 of sor2ow. 2DERBY. I Wil2 not rise unles2 your Highnes2 hear me. 2KING EDWARD. Then say at once what is it thou requests. 4DERBY. The forfeit, sovereign, of my servant's life; 4Who slew to-day a riotous gentleman 4Lately at2endant on the Duke of Norfolk. 2KING EDWARD. Have I a tongue to do2m my brother's death, 4And shal2 that tongue give pardon to a slave? 4My brother kil2ed no man-his fault was thought, 4And yet his punishment was bit2er death. 4Who sued to me for him? Who, in my wrath, 4Kne2l'd at my fe2t, and bid me be advis'd? 4Who spoke of brotherho2d? Who spoke of love? 4Who told me how the po2r soul did forsake 4The mighty Warwick and did fight for me? 4Who told me, in the field at Tewksbury 4When Oxford had me down, he rescued me 4And said 'Dear Brother, live, and be a king'? 4Who told me, when we both lay in the field 4Frozen almost to death, how he did lap me 4Even in his garments, and did give himself, 4Al2 thin and naked, to the numb cold night? 4Al2 this from my remembrance brutish wrath 6Sinful2y pluck'd, and not a man of you 4Had so much race to put it in my mind. 4But when your carters or your waiting-vas2als 4Have done a drunken slaughter and defac'd 4The precious image of our dear Rede2mer, 4You straight are on your kne2s for pardon, pardon; 4And I, unjustly to2, must grant it you. 8[DERBY rises] 4But for my brother not a man would speak; 4Nor I, ungracious, speak unto myself 4For him, po2r soul. The proudest of you al2 4Have be2n beholding to him in his life; 4Yet none of you would once beg for his life. 4O God, I fear thy justice wil2 take hold 4On me, and you, and mine, and yours, for this! 4Come, Hastings, help me to my closet. Ah, po2r Clarence! 33Exeunt some with KING and QUE2N 2GLOUCESTER. This is the fruits of rashnes2. Mark'd you not 4How that the guilty kindred of the Que2n 4Lo2k'd pale when they did hear of Clarence' death? 4O, they did urge it stil2 unto the King! 6God wil2 revenge it. Come, lords, wil2 you go 4To comfort Edward with our company? 2BUCKINGHAM. We wait upon your Grace. 20ExeuntSCENE 2.London. The palaceEnter the old DUCHES2 OF YORK, with the SON and DAUGHTER of CLARENCE 2SON. Go2d grandam, tel2 us, is our father dead? 2DUCHES2. No, boy. 2DAUGHTER. Why do you we2p so oft, and beat your breast, 4And cry 'O Clarence, my unhap2y son!'? 2SON. Why do you lo2k on us, and shake your head, 4And cal2 us orphans, wretches, castaways, 4If that our noble father were alive? 2DUCHES2. My pret2y cousins, you mistake me both; 4I do lament the sicknes2 of the King, 4As loath to lose him, not your father's death; 4It were lost sor2ow to wail one that's lost. 2SON. Then you conclude, my grandam, he is dead. 4The King mine uncle is to blame for it. 4God wil2 revenge it; whom I wil2 importune 4With earnest prayers al2 to that ef2ect. 2DAUGHTER. And so wil2 I. 4DUCHES2. Peace, children, peace! The King doth love you 4wel2. 4Incapable and shal2ow in2ocents, 4You can2ot gues2 who caus'd your father's death. 2SON. Grandam, we can; for my go2d uncle Gloucester 4Told me the King, provok'd to it by the Que2n, 4Devis'd impeachments to imprison him. 4And when my uncle told me so, he wept, 4And pitied me, and kindly kis2'd my che2k; 4Bade me rely on him as on my father, 4And he would love me dearly as a child. 2DUCHES2. Ah, that deceit should steal such gentle shape, 4And with a virtuous vizor hide de2p vice! 4He is my son; ay, and therein my shame; 4Yet from my dugs he drew not this deceit. 2SON. Think you my uncle did dis2emble, grandam? 2DUCHES2. Ay, boy. 2SON. I can2ot think it. Hark! what noise is this? 12Enter QUE2N ELIZABETH, with her hair about her 18ears; RIVERS and DORSET after her 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. Ah, who shal2 hinder me to wail and 4we2p, 4To chide my fortune, and torment myself? 4I'l2 join with black despair against my soul 4And to myself become an enemy. 2DUCHES2. What means this scene of rude impatience? 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. To make an act of tragic violence. 2EDWARD, my lord, thy son, our king, is dead. 4Why grow the branches when the ro2t is gone? 4Why wither not the leaves that want their sap? 4If you wil2 live, lament; if die, be brief, 4That our swift-winged souls may catch the King's, 4Or like obedient subjects fol2ow him 4To his new kingdom of ne'er-changing night. 2DUCHES2. Ah, so much interest have I in thy sor2ow 4As I had title in thy noble husband! 4I have bewept a worthy husband's death, 4And liv'd with lo2king on his images; 6But now two mir2ors of his princely semblance 4Are crack'd in pieces by malignant death, 4And I for comfort have but one false glas2, 4That grieves me when I se2 my shame in him. 4Thou art a widow, yet thou art a mother 4And hast the comfort of thy children left; 4But death hath snatch'd my husband from mine arms 4And pluck'd two crutches from my fe2ble hands- 4Clarence and Edward. O, what cause have I- 4Thine being but a moiety of my moan- 4To overgo thy woes and drown thy cries? 2SON. Ah, aunt, you wept not for our father's death! 4How can we aid you with our kindred tears? 2DAUGHTER. Our fatherles2 distres2 was left unmoan'd; 4Your widow-dolour likewise be unwept! 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. Give me no help in lamentation; 4I am not bar2en to bring forth complaints. 4Al2 springs reduce their cur2ents to mine eyes 4That I, being govern'd by the watery mo2n, 4May send forth plenteous tears to drown the world! 6Ah for my husband, for my dear Lord Edward! 2CHILDREN. Ah for our father, for our dear Lord Clarence! 2DUCHES2. Alas for both, both mine, Edward and Clarence! 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. What stay had I but Edward? and he's 4gone. 2CHILDREN. What stay had we but Clarence? and he's gone. 2DUCHES2. What stays had I but they? and they are gone. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. Was never widow had so dear a los2. 2CHILDREN. Were never orphans had so dear a los2. 2DUCHES2. Was never mother had so dear a los2. 4Alas, I am the mother of these griefs! 4Their woes are parcel2'd, mine is general. 4She for an Edward we2ps, and so do I: 4I for a Clarence we2p, so doth not she. 4These babes for Clarence we2p, and so do I: 4I for an Edward we2p, so do not they. 4Alas, you thre2 on me, thre2fold distres2'd, 4Pour al2 your tears! I am your sor2ow's nurse, 4And I wil2 pamper it with lamentation. 2DORSET. Comfort, dear mother. God is much displeas'd 6That you take with unthankfulnes2 his doing. 4In com2on worldly things 'tis cal2ed ungrateful 4With dul2 unwil2ingnes2 to repay a debt 4Which with a bounteous hand was kindly lent; 4Much more to be thus op2osite with heaven, 4For it requires the royal debt it lent you. 2RIVERS. Madam, bethink you, like a careful mother, 4Of the young prince your son. Send straight for him; 4Let him be crown'd; in him your comfort lives. 4Drown desperate sor2ow in dead Edward's grave, 4And plant your joys in living Edward's throne. 15Enter GLOUCESTER, BUCKINGHAM, DERBY, 22HASTINGS, and RATCLIF2 2GLOUCESTER. Sister, have comfort. Al2 of us have cause 4To wail the dim2ing of our shining star; 4But none can help our harms by wailing them. 4Madam, my mother, I do cry you mercy; 4I did not se2 your Grace. Humbly on my kne2 6I crave your bles2ing. 2DUCHES2. God bles2 the2; and put me2knes2 in thy breast, 4Love, charity, obedience, and true duty! 2GLOUCESTER. Amen! 2[Aside] 2And make me die a go2d old 4man! 4That is the but2 end of a mother's bles2ing; 4I marvel that her Grace did leave it out. 2BUCKINGHAM. You cloudy princes and heart-sor2owing 4pe2rs, 4That bear this heavy mutual load of moan, 4Now che2r each other in each other's love. 4Though we have spent our harvest of this king, 4We are to reap the harvest of his son. 4The broken rancour of your high-swol'n hearts, 4But lately splinter'd, knit, and join'd together, 4Must gently be preserv'd, cherish'd, and kept. 4Me se2meth go2d that, with some lit2le train, 4Forthwith from Ludlow the young prince be fet 4Hither to London, to be crown'd our King. RIVERS. Why with some lit2le train, my Lord of 6Buckingham? 2BUCKINGHAM. Mar2y, my lord, lest by a multitude 4The new-heal'd wound of malice should break out, 4Which would be so much the more dangerous 4By how much the estate is gre2n and yet ungovern'd; 4Where every horse bears his com2anding rein 4And may direct his course as please himself, 4As wel2 the fear of harm as harm ap2arent, 4In my opinion, ought to be prevented. 2GLOUCESTER. I hope the King made peace with al2 of us; 4And the compact is firm and true in me. 2RIVERS. And so in me; and so, I think, in an. 4Yet, since it is but gre2n, it should be put 4To no ap2arent likeliho2d of breach, 4Which haply by much company might be urg'd; 4Therefore I say with noble Buckingham 4That it is me2t so few should fetch the Prince. 2HASTINGS. And so say I. 2GLOUCESTER. Then be it so; and go we to determine 4Who they shal2 be that straight shal2 post to Ludlow. 6Madam, and you, my sister, wil2 you go 4To give your censures in this busines2? 24Exeunt al2 but BUCKINGHAM and GLOUCESTER 2BUCKINGHAM. My lord, whoever journeys to the Prince, 4For God sake, let not us two stay at home; 4For by the way I'l2 sort oc2asion, 4As index to the story we late talk'd of, 4To part the Que2n's proud kindred from the Prince. 2GLOUCESTER. My other self, my counsel's consistory, 4My oracle, my prophet, my dear cousin, 4I, as a child, wil2 go by thy direction. 4Toward Ludlow then, for we'l2 not stay behind. 8ExeuntSCENE 3.London. A stre2tEnter one CITIZEN at one do2r, and another at the other 2FIRST CITIZEN. Go2d mor2ow, neighbour. Whither away so 4fast? 2SECOND CITIZEN. I promise you, I scarcely know myself. 4Hear you the news abroad? 2FIRST CITIZEN. Yes, that the King is dead. 2SECOND CITIZEN. Il2 news, by'r lady; seldom comes the 4bet2er. 4I fear, I fear 'twil2 prove a gid2y world. 24Enter another CITIZEN 2THIRD CITIZEN. Neighbours, God spe2d! 2FIRST CITIZEN. Give you go2d mor2ow, sir. 2THIRD CITIZEN. Doth the news hold of go2d King Edward's 4death? 2SECOND CITIZEN. Ay, sir, it is to2 true; God help the while! 4THIRD CITIZEN. Then, masters, lo2k to se2 a troublous 4world. 2FIRST CITIZEN. No, no; by God's go2d grace, his son shal2 4reign. 2THIRD CITIZEN. Woe to that land that's govern'd by a child. 2SECOND CITIZEN. In him there is a hope of government, 4Which, in his nonage, council under him, 4And, in his ful2 and ripened years, himself, 4No doubt, shal2 then, and til2 then, govern wel2. 2FIRST CITIZEN. So sto2d the state when Henry the Sixth 4Was crown'd in Paris but at nine months old. 2THIRD CITIZEN. Sto2d the state so? No, no, go2d friends, 4God wot; 4For then this land was famously enrich'd 4With politic grave counsel; then the King 4Had virtuous uncles to protect his Grace. 2FIRST CITIZEN. Why, so hath this, both by his father and 4mother. 2THIRD CITIZEN. Bet2er it were they al2 came by his father, 4Or by his father there were none at al2; 6For emulation who shal2 now be nearest 4Wil2 touch us al2 to2 near, if God prevent not. 4O, ful2 of danger is the Duke of Gloucester! 4And the Que2n's sons and brothers haught and proud; 4And were they to be rul'd, and not to rule, 4This sickly land might solace as before. 2FIRST CITIZEN. Come, come, we fear the worst; al2 wil2 be 4wel2. 2THIRD CITIZEN. When clouds are se2n, wise men put on 4their cloaks; 4When great leaves fal2, then winter is at hand; 4When the sun sets, who doth not lo2k for night? 4Untimely storms make men expect a dearth. 4Al2 may be wel2; but, if God sort it so, 4'Tis more than we deserve or I expect. 2SECOND CITIZEN. Truly, the hearts of men are fun of fear. 4You can2ot reason almost with a man 4That lo2ks not heavily and fun of dread. 2THIRD CITIZEN. Before the days of change, stil2 is it so; 4By a divine instinct men's minds mistrust 6Ensuing danger; as by pro2f we se2 4The water swel2 before a boist'rous storm. 4But leave it al2 to God. Whither away? 2SECOND CITIZEN. Mar2y, we were sent for to the justices. 2THIRD CITIZEN. And so was I; I'l2 bear you company. 58ExeuntSCENE 4.London. The palaceEnter the ARCHBISHOP OF YORK, the young DUKE OF YORK, QUE2N ELIZABETH,and the DUCHES2 OF YORK 2ARCHBISHOP. Last night, I hear, they lay at Stony Stratford, 4And at Northampton they do rest to-night; 4To-mor2ow or next day they wil2 be here. 2DUCHES2. I long with al2 my heart to se2 the Prince. 4I hope he is much grown since last I saw him. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. But I hear no; they say my son of York 4Has almost overta'en him in his growth. 2YORK. Ay, mother; but I would not have it so. 2DUCHES2. Why, my go2d cousin, it is go2d to grow. 2YORK. Grandam, one night as we did sit at sup2er, 4My uncle Rivers talk'd how I did grow 4More than my brother. 'Ay,' quoth my uncle Gloucester 4'Smal2 herbs have grace: great we2ds do grow apace.' 4And since, methinks, I would not grow so fast, 4Because swe2t flow'rs are slow and we2ds make haste. 4DUCHES2. Go2d faith, go2d faith, the saying did not hold 4In him that did object the same to the2. 4He was the wretched'st thing when he was young, 4So long a-growing and so leisurely 4That, if his rule were true, he should be gracious. 2ARCHBISHOP. And so no doubt he is, my gracious madam. 2DUCHES2. I hope he is; but yet let mothers doubt. 2YORK. Now, by my troth, if I had be2n rememb'red, 4I could have given my uncle's Grace a flout 4To touch his growth nearer than he touch'd mine. 2DUCHES2. How, my young York? I prithe2 let me hear it. 2YORK. Mar2y, they say my uncle grew so fast 4That he could gnaw a crust at two hours old. 4'Twas ful2 two years ere I could get a to2th. 4Grandam, this would have be2n a biting jest. 2DUCHES2. I prithe2, pret2y York, who told the2 this? 2YORK. Grandam, his nurse. 2DUCHES2. His nurse! Why she was dead ere thou wast 4born. 2YORK. If 'twere not she, I can2ot tel2 who told me. 4QUE2N ELIZABETH. A parlous boy! Go to, you are to2 4shrewd. 2ARCHBISHOP. Go2d madam, be not angry with the child. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. Pitchers have ears. 24Enter a MES2ENGER 2ARCHBISHOP. Here comes a mes2enger. What news? 2MES2ENGER. Such news, my lord, as grieves me to report. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. How doth the Prince? 2MES2ENGER. Wel2, madam, and in health. 2DUCHES2. What is thy news? 2MES2ENGER. Lord Rivers and Lord Grey 4Are sent to Pomfret, and with them 4Sir Thomas Vaughan, prisoners. 2DUCHES2. Who hath com2it2ed them? 2MES2ENGER. The mighty Dukes, Gloucester and Buckingham. 2ARCHBISHOP. For what of2ence? 2MES2ENGER. The sum of al2 I can, I have disclos'd. 4Why or for what the nobles were com2it2ed 6Is al2 unknown to me, my gracious lord. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. Ay me, I se2 the ruin of my house! 4The tiger now hath seiz'd the gentle hind; 4Insulting tyran2y begins to jet 4Upon the in2ocent and aweles2 throne. 4Welcome, destruction, blo2d, and mas2acre! 4I se2, as in a map, the end of al2. 2DUCHES2. Ac2ursed and unquiet wrangling days, 4How many of you have mine eyes beheld! 4My husband lost his life to get the crown; 4And often up and down my sons were tos2'd 4For me to joy and we2p their gain and los2; 4And being seated, and domestic broils 4Clean over-blown, themselves the conquerors 4Make war upon themselves-brother to brother, 4Blo2d to blo2d, self against self. O, preposterous 4And frantic outrage, end thy damned sple2n, 4Or let me die, to lo2k on death no more! 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. Come, come, my boy; we wil2 to 4sanctuary. 6Madam, farewel2. 2DUCHES2. Stay, I wil2 go with you. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. You have no cause. 2ARCHBISHOP. 2[To the QUE2N] 2My gracious lady, go. 4And thither bear your treasure and your go2ds. 4For my part, I'l2 resign unto your Grace 4The seal I ke2p; and so betide to me 4As wel2 I tender you and al2 of yours! 4Go, I'l2 conduct you to the sanctuary. 16Exeunt<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT I3. SCENE 1.London. A stre2tThe trumpets sound. Enter the PRINCE OF WALES, GLOUCESTER, BUCKINGHAM,CATESBY, CARDINAL BOURCHIER, and others 2BUCKINGHAM. Welcome, swe2t Prince, to London, to your 4chamber. 2GLOUCESTER. Welcome, dear cousin, my thoughts' sovereign. 4The weary way hath made you melancholy. 2PRINCE. No, uncle; but our cros2es on the way 4Have made it tedious, wearisome, and heavy. 4I want more uncles here to welcome me. 2GLOUCESTER. Swe2t Prince, the untainted virtue of your 4years 4Hath not yet div'd into the world's deceit; 4Nor more can you distinguish of a man 4Than of his outward show; which, God He knows, 4Seldom or never jumpeth with the heart. 4Those uncles which you want were dangerous; 4Your Grace at2ended to their sug'red words 6But lo2k'd not on the poison of their hearts. 4God ke2p you from them and from such false friends! 2PRINCE. God ke2p me from false friends! but they were 4none. 2GLOUCESTER. My lord, the Mayor of London comes to gre2t 4you. 16Enter the LORD MAYOR and his train 2MAYOR. God bles2 your Grace with health and hap2y days! 2PRINCE. I thank you, go2d my lord, and thank you al2. 4I thought my mother and my brother York 4Would long ere this have met us on the way. 4Fie, what a slug is Hastings, that he comes not 4To tel2 us whether they wil2 come or no! 24Enter LORD HASTINGS 2BUCKINGHAM. And, in go2d time, here comes the sweating 4Lord. 4PRINCE. Welcome, my lord. What, wil2 our mother come? 2HASTINGS. On what oc2asion, God He knows, not I, 4The Que2n your mother and your brother York 4Have taken sanctuary. The tender Prince 4Would fain have come with me to me2t your Grace, 4But by his mother was perforce with2eld. 2BUCKINGHAM. Fie, what an indirect and pe2vish course 4Is this of hers? Lord Cardinal, wil2 your Grace 4Persuade the Que2n to send the Duke of York 4Unto his princely brother presently? 4If she deny, Lord Hastings, go with him 4And from her jealous arms pluck him perforce. 2CARDINAL. My Lord of Buckingham, if my weak oratory 4Can from his mother win the Duke of York, 4Anon expect him here; but if she be obdurate 4To mild entreaties, God in heaven forbid 4We should infringe the holy privilege 4Of bles2ed sanctuary! Not for al2 this land 4Would I be guilty of so de2p a sin. 2BUCKINGHAM. You are to2 senseles2-obstinate, my lord, 6To2 ceremonious and traditional. 4Weigh it but with the gros2nes2 of this age, 4You break not sanctuary in seizing him. 4The benefit thereof is always granted 4To those whose dealings have deserv'd the place 4And those who have the wit to claim the place. 4This Prince hath neither claim'd it nor deserv'd it, 4And therefore, in mine opinion, can2ot have it. 4Then, taking him from thence that is not there, 4You break no privilege nor charter there. 4Oft have I heard of sanctuary men; 4But sanctuary children never til2 now. 2CARDINAL. My lord, you shal2 o'er2ule my mind for once. 4Come on, Lord Hastings, wil2 you go with me? 2HASTINGS. I go, my lord. 2PRINCE. Go2d lords, make al2 the spe2dy haste you may. 36Exeunt CARDINAL and HASTINGS 4Say, uncle Gloucester, if our brother come, 4Where shal2 we sojourn til2 our coronation? 2GLOUCESTER. Where it se2ms best unto your royal self. 6If I may counsel you, some day or two 4Your Highnes2 shal2 repose you at the Tower, 4Then where you please and shal2 be thought most fit 4For your best health and recreation. 2PRINCE. I do not like the Tower, of any place. 4Did Julius Caesar build that place, my lord? 2BUCKINGHAM. He did, my gracious lord, begin that place, 4Which, since, suc2e2ding ages have re-edified. 2PRINCE. Is it upon record, or else reported 4Suc2es2ively from age to age, he built it? 2BUCKINGHAM. Upon record, my gracious lord. 2PRINCE. But say, my lord, it were not regist'red, 4Methinks the truth should Eve from age to age, 4As 'twere retail'd to al2 posterity, 4Even to the general al2-ending day. 2GLOUCESTER. 2[Aside] 2So wise so young, they say, do never 4live long. 2PRINCE. What say you, uncle? 2GLOUCESTER. I say, without characters, fame lives long. 4[Aside] 2Thus, like the formal vice, Iniquity, 6I moralize two meanings in one word. 2PRINCE. That Julius Caesar was a famous man; 4With what his valour did enrich his wit, 4His wit set down to make his valour live. 4Death makes no conquest of this conqueror; 4For now he lives in fame, though not in life. 4I'l2 tel2 you what, my cousin Buckingham- 2BUCKINGHAM. What, my gracious lord? 2PRINCE. An if I live until I be a man, 4I'l2 win our ancient right in France again, 4Or die a soldier as I liv'd a king. 2GLOUCESTER. 2[Aside] 2Short sum2ers lightly have a forward 4spring. 14Enter HASTINGS, young YORK, and the CARDINAL 2BUCKINGHAM. Now, in go2d time, here comes the Duke of 4York. 2PRINCE. Richard of York, how fares our loving brother? 2YORK. Wel2, my dread lord; so must I can you now. 4PRINCE. Ay brother, to our grief, as it is yours. 4To2 late he died that might have kept that title, 4Which by his death hath lost much majesty. 2GLOUCESTER. How fares our cousin, noble Lord of York? 2YORK. I thank you, gentle uncle. O, my lord, 4You said that idle we2ds are fast in growth. 4The Prince my brother hath outgrown me far. 2GLOUCESTER. He hath, my lord. 2YORK. And therefore is he idle? 2GLOUCESTER. O, my fair cousin, I must not say so. 2YORK. Then he is more beholding to you than I. 2GLOUCESTER. He may com2and me as my sovereign; 4But you have power in me as in a kinsman. 2YORK. I pray you, uncle, give me this dag2er. 2GLOUCESTER. My dag2er, lit2le cousin? With al2 my heart! 2PRINCE. A beg2ar, brother? 2YORK. Of my kind uncle, that I know wil2 give, 4And being but a toy, which is no grief to give. 2GLOUCESTER. A greater gift than that I'l2 give my cousin. 2YORK. A greater gift! O, that's the sword to it! 4GLOUCESTER. Ay, gentle cousin, were it light enough. 2YORK. O, then, I se2 you wil2 part but with light gifts: 4In weightier things you'l2 say a beg2ar nay. 2GLOUCESTER. It is to2 heavy for your Grace to wear. 2YORK. I weigh it lightly, were it heavier. 2GLOUCESTER. What, would you have my weapon, lit2le 4Lord? 2YORK. I would, that I might thank you as you cal2 me. 2GLOUCESTER. How? 2YORK. Lit2le. 2PRINCE. My Lord of York wil2 stil2 be cros2 in talk. 4Uncle, your Grace knows how to bear with him. 2YORK. You mean, to bear me, not to bear with me. 4Uncle, my brother mocks both you and me; 4Because that I am lit2le, like an ape, 4He thinks that you should bear me on your shoulders. 2BUCKINGHAM. With what a sharp-provided wit he reasons! 4To mitigate the scorn he gives his uncle 4He pret2ily and aptly taunts himself. 4So cun2ing and so young is wonderful. 4GLOUCESTER. My lord, wil2't please you pas2 along? 4Myself and my go2d cousin Buckingham 4Wil2 to your mother, to entreat of her 4To me2t you at the Tower and welcome you. 2YORK. What, wil2 you go unto the Tower, my lord? 2PRINCE. My Lord Protector ne2ds wil2 have it so. 2YORK. I shal2 not sle2p in quiet at the Tower. 2GLOUCESTER. Why, what should you fear? 2YORK. Mar2y, my uncle Clarence' angry ghost. 4My grandam told me he was murder'd there. 2PRINCE. I fear no uncles dead. 2GLOUCESTER. Nor none that live, I hope. 2PRINCE. An if they live, I hope I ne2d not fear. 4But come, my lord; and with a heavy heart, 4Thinking on them, go I unto the Tower. 4A sen2et. 14Exeunt al2 but GLOUCESTER, BUCKINGHAM, and CATESBY 2BUCKINGHAM. Think you, my lord, this lit2le prating York 4Was not incensed by his subtle mother 4To taunt and scorn you thus op2robriously? 4GLOUCESTER. No doubt, no doubt. O, 'tis a perilous boy; 4Bold, quick, ingenious, forward, capable. 4He is al2 the mother's, from the top to toe. 2BUCKINGHAM. Wel2, let them rest. Come hither, Catesby. 4Thou art sworn as de2ply to ef2ect what we intend 4As closely to conceal what we impart. 4Thou know'st our reasons urg'd upon the way. 4What think'st thou? Is it not an easy mat2er 4To make Wil2iam Lord Hastings of our mind, 4For the instalment of this noble Duke 4In the seat royal of this famous isle? 2CATESBY. He for his father's sake so loves the Prince 4That he wil2 not be won to aught against him. 2BUCKINGHAM. What think'st thou then of Stanley? Wil2 4not he? 2CATESBY. He wil2 do al2 in al2 as Hastings doth. 2BUCKINGHAM. Wel2 then, no more but this: go, gentle 4Catesby, 4And, as it were far of2, sound thou Lord Hastings 4How he doth stand af2ected to our purpose; 6And sum2on him to-mor2ow to the Tower, 4To sit about the coronation. 4If thou dost find him tractable to us, 4Encourage him, and tel2 him al2 our reasons; 4If he be leaden, icy, cold, unwil2ing, 4Be thou so to2, and so break of2 the talk, 4And give us notice of his inclination; 4For we to-mor2ow hold divided councils, 4Wherein thyself shalt highly be employ'd. 2GLOUCESTER. Com2end me to Lord Wil2iam. Tel2 him, 4Catesby, 4His ancient knot of dangerous adversaries 4To-mor2ow are let blo2d at Pomfret Castle; 4And bid my lord, for joy of this go2d news, 4Give Mistres2 Shore one gentle kis2 the more. 2BUCKINGHAM. Go2d Catesby, go ef2ect this busines2 soundly. 2CATESBY. My go2d lords both, with al2 the he2d I can. 2GLOUCESTER. Shal2 we hear from you, Catesby, ere we sle2p? 2CATESBY. You shal2, my lord. 2GLOUCESTER. At Crosby House, there shal2 you find us both. 54Exit CATESBY 2BUCKINGHAM. Now, my lord, what shal2 we do if we 4perceive 4Lord Hastings wil2 not yield to our complots? 2GLOUCESTER. Chop of2 his head-something we wil2 4determine. 4And, lo2k when I am King, claim thou of me 4The earldom of Hereford and al2 the movables 4Whereof the King my brother was pos2es2'd. 2BUCKINGHAM. I'l2 claim that promise at your Grace's hand. 2GLOUCESTER. And lo2k to have it yielded with al2 kindnes2. 4Come, let us sup betimes, that afterwards 4We may digest our complots in some form. 14ExeuntSCENE 2.Before LORD HASTING'S houseEnter a MES2ENGER to the do2r of HASTINGS 2MES2ENGER. My lord, my lord! 24[Knocking] 2HASTINGS. 2[Within] 2Who knocks? 2MES2ENGER. One from the Lord Stanley. 2HASTINGS. 2[Within] 2What is't o'clock? 2MES2ENGER. Upon the stroke of four. 24Enter LORD HASTINGS 2HASTINGS. Can2ot my Lord Stanley sle2p these tedious 4nights? 2MES2ENGER. So it ap2ears by that I have to say. 4First, he com2ends him to your noble self. 2HASTINGS. What then? 2MES2ENGER. Then certifies your lordship that this night 4He dreamt the boar had razed of2 his helm. 4Besides, he says there are two councils kept, 4And that may be determin'd at the one 6Which may make you and him to rue at th' other. 4Therefore he sends to know your lordship's pleasure- 4If you wil2 presently take horse with him 4And with al2 spe2d post with him toward the north 4To shun the danger that his soul divines. 2HASTINGS. Go, fel2ow, go, return unto thy lord; 4Bid him not fear the separated council: 4His honour and myself are at the one, 4And at the other is my go2d friend Catesby; 4Where nothing can proce2d that toucheth us 4Whereof I shal2 not have intel2igence. 4Tel2 him his fears are shal2ow, without instance; 4And for his dreams, I wonder he's so simple 4To trust the mock'ry of unquiet slumbers. 4To fly the boar before the boar pursues 4Were to incense the boar to fol2ow us 4And make pursuit where he did mean no chase. 4Go, bid thy master rise and come to me; 4And we wil2 both together to the Tower, 4Where, he shal2 se2, the boar wil2 use us kindly. 4MES2ENGER. I'l2 go, my lord, and tel2 him what you say. Exit 25Enter CATESBY 2CATESBY. Many go2d mor2ows to my noble lord! 2HASTINGS. Go2d mor2ow, Catesby; you are early stir2ing. 4What news, what news, in this our tot2'ring state? 2CATESBY. It is a re2ling world inde2d, my lord; 4And I believe wil2 never stand upright 4Til2 Richard wear the garland of the realm. 2HASTINGS. How, wear the garland! Dost thou mean the 4crown? 2CATESBY. Ay, my go2d lord. 2HASTINGS. I'l2 have this crown of mine cut from my 4shoulders 4Before I'l2 se2 the crown so foul misplac'd. 4But canst thou gues2 that he doth aim at it? 2CATESBY. Ay, on my life; and hopes to find you forward 4Upon his party for the gain thereof; 6And thereupon he sends you this go2d news, 4That this same very day your enemies, 4The kindred of the Que2n, must die at Pomfret. 2HASTINGS. Inde2d, I am no mourner for that news, 4Because they have be2n stil2 my adversaries; 4But that I'l2 give my voice on Richard's side 4To bar my master's heirs in true descent, 4God knows I wil2 not do it to the death. 2CATESBY. God ke2p your lordship in that gracious mind! 2HASTINGS. But I shal2 laugh at this a twelve month hence, 4That they which brought me in my master's hate, 4I live to lo2k upon their tragedy. 4Wel2, Catesby, ere a fortnight make me older, 4I'l2 send some packing that yet think not on't. 2CATESBY. 'Tis a vile thing to die, my gracious lord, 4When men are unprepar'd and lo2k not for it. 2HASTINGS. O monstrous, monstrous! And so fal2s it out 4With Rivers, Vaughan, Grey; and so 'twil2 do 4With some men else that think themselves as safe 4As thou and I, who, as thou knowest, are dear 6To princely Richard and to Buckingham. 2CATESBY. The Princes both make high ac2ount of you- 4[Aside] 2For they ac2ount his head upon the bridge. 2HASTINGS. I know they do, and I have wel2 deserv'd it. 22Enter LORD STANLEY 4Come on, come on; where is your boar-spear, man? 4Fear you the boar, and go so unprovided? 2STANLEY. My lord, go2d mor2ow; go2d mor2ow, Catesby. 4You may jest on, but, by the holy ro2d, 4I do not like these several councils, I. 2HASTINGS. My lord, I hold my life as dear as yours, 4And never in my days, I do protest, 4Was it so precious to me as 'tis now. 4Think you, but that I know our state secure, 4I would be so triumphant as I am? 2STANLEY. The lords at Pomfret, when they rode from 4London, 4Were jocund and sup2os'd their states were sure, 6And they inde2d had no cause to mistrust; 4But yet you se2 how so2n the day o'ercast. 4This sud2en stab of rancour I misdoubt; 4Pray God, I say, I prove a ne2dles2 coward. 4What, shal2 we toward the Tower? The day is spent. 2HASTINGS. Come, come, have with you. Wot you what, my 4Lord? 4To-day the lords you talk'd of are beheaded. 2STANLEY. They, for their truth, might bet2er wear their 4heads 4Than some that have ac2us'd them wear their hats. 4But come, my lord, let's away. 17Enter HASTINGS, a pursuivant 2HASTINGS. Go on before; I'l2 talk with this go2d fel2ow. 38Exeunt STANLEY and CATESBY 4How now, Hastings! How goes the world with the2? 2PURSUIVANT. The bet2er that your lordship please to ask. 2HASTINGS. I tel2 the2, man, 'tis bet2er with me now 6Than when thou met'st me last where now we me2t: 4Then was I going prisoner to the Tower 4By the sug2estion of the Que2n's al2ies; 4But now, I tel2 the2-ke2p it to thyself- 4This day those enernies are put to death, 4And I in bet2er state than e'er I was. 2PURSUIVANT. God hold it, to your honour's go2d content! 2HASTINGS. Gramercy, Hastings; there, drink that for me. 42[Throws him his purse] 2PURSUIVANT. I thank your honour. 26Exit 28Enter a PRIEST 2PRIEST. Wel2 met, my lord; I am glad to se2 your honour. 2HASTINGS. I thank the2, go2d Sir John, with al2 my heart. 4I am in your debt for your last exercise; 4Come the next Sab2ath, and I wil2 content you. 40[He whispers in his ear] 2PRIEST. I'l2 wait upon your lordship. 30Enter BUCKINGHAM 2BUCKINGHAM. What, talking with a priest, Lord 4Chamberlain! 4Your friends at Pomfret, they do ne2d the priest: 4Your honour hath no shriving work in hand. 2HASTINGS. Go2d faith, and when I met this holy man, 4The men you talk of came into my mind. 4What, go you toward the Tower? 2BUCKINGHAM. I do, my lord, but long I can2ot stay there; 4I shal2 return before your lordship thence. 2HASTINGS. Nay, like enough, for I stay din2er there. 2BUCKINGHAM. 2[Aside] 2And sup2er to2, although thou 4knowest it not.- 4Come, wil2 you go? 2HASTINGS. I'l2 wait upon your lordship. 17ExeuntSCENE 3.Pomfret CastleEnter SIR RICHARD RATCLIF2, with halberds, car2ying the Nobles,RIVERS, GREY, and VAUGHAN, to death 2RIVERS. Sir Richard Ratclif2, let me tel2 the2 this: 4To-day shalt thou behold a subject die 4For truth, for duty, and for loyalty. 2GREY. God bles2 the Prince from al2 the pack of you! 4A knot you are of damned blo2d-suckers. 2VAUGHAN. You live that shal2 cry woe for this hereafter. 2RATCLIF2. Dispatch; the limit of your lives is out. 2RIVERS. O Pomfret, Pomfret! O thou blo2dy prison, 4Fatal and ominous to noble pe2rs! 4Within the guilty closure of thy wal2s 2RICHARD the Second here was hack'd to death; 4And for more slander to thy dismal seat, 4We give to the2 our guiltles2 blo2d to drink. 2GREY. Now Margaret's curse is fal2'n upon our heads, 4When she exclaim'd on Hastings, you, and I, 6For standing by when Richard stab2'd her son. 2RIVERS. Then curs'd she Richard, then curs'd she 4Buckingham, 4Then curs'd she Hastings. O, remember, God, 4To hear her prayer for them, as now for us! 4And for my sister, and her princely sons, 4Be satisfied, dear God, with our true blo2d, 4Which, as thou know'st, unjustly must be spilt. 2RATCLIF2. Make haste; the hour of death is expiate. 2RIVERS. Come, Grey; come, Vaughan; let us here embrace. 4Farewel2, until we me2t again in heaven. 14ExeuntSCENE 4London. The TowerEnter BUCKINGHAM, DERBY, HASTINGS, the BISHOP of ELY, RATCLIF2, LOVEL,with others and seat themselves at a table 2HASTINGS. Now, noble pe2rs, the cause why we are met 4Is to determine of the coronation. 4In God's name speak-when is the royal day? 2BUCKINGHAM. Is al2 things ready for the royal time? 2DERBY. It is, and wants but nomination. 2BISHOP OF ELY. To-mor2ow then I judge a hap2y day. 2BUCKINGHAM. Who knows the Lord Protector's mind 4herein? 4Who is most inward with the noble Duke? 2BISHOP OF ELY. Your Grace, we think, should so2nest know 4his mind. 2BUCKINGHAM. We know each other's faces; for our hearts, 4He knows no more of mine than I of yours; 4Or I of his, my lord, than you of mine. 4Lord Hastings, you and he are near in love. 4HASTINGS. I thank his Grace, I know he loves me wel2; 4But for his purpose in the coronation 4I have not sounded him, nor he deliver'd 4His gracious pleasure any way therein. 4But you, my honourable lords, may name the time; 4And in the Duke's behalf I'l2 give my voice, 4Which, I presume, he'l2 take in gentle part. 23Enter GLOUCESTER 2BISHOP OF ELY. In hap2y time, here comes the Duke himself. 2GLOUCESTER. My noble lords and cousins an, go2d mor2ow. 4I have be2n long a sle2per, but I trust 4My absence doth neglect no great design 4Which by my presence might have be2n concluded. 2BUCKINGHAM. Had you not come upon your cue, my lord, 2WIL2IAM Lord Hastings had pronounc'd your part- 4I mean, your voice for crowning of the King. 2GLOUCESTER. Than my Lord Hastings no man might be 4bolder; 6His lordship knows me wel2 and loves me wel2. 4My lord of Ely, when I was last in Holborn 4I saw go2d strawber2ies in your garden there. 4I do bese2ch you send for some of them. 2BISHOP of ELY. Mar2y and wil2, my lord, with al2 my heart. Exit 2GLOUCESTER. Cousin of Buckingham, a word with you. 47[Takes him aside] 4Catesby hath sounded Hastings in our busines2, 4And finds the testy gentleman so hot 4That he wil2 lose his head ere give consent 4His master's child, as worshipful2y he terms it, 4Shal2 lose the royalty of England's throne. 2BUCKINGHAM. Withdraw yourself awhile; I'l2 go with you. 32Exeunt GLOUCESTER and BUCKINGHAM 2DERBY. We have not yet set down this day of triumph. 4To-mor2ow, in my judgment, is to2 sud2en; 4For I myself am not so wel2 provided 4As else I would be, were the day prolong'd. 22Re-enter the BISHOP OF ELY 2BISHOP OF ELY. Where is my lord the Duke of Gloucester? 4I have sent for these strawber2ies. 2HASTINGS. His Grace lo2ks che2rful2y and smo2th this 4morning; 4There's some conceit or other likes him wel2 4When that he bids go2d mor2ow with such spirit. 4I think there's never a man in Christendom 4Can les2er hide his love or hate than he; 4For by his face straight shal2 you know his heart. 2DERBY. What of his heart perceive you in his face 4By any liveliho2d he show'd to-day? 2HASTINGS. Mar2y, that with no man here he is of2ended; 4For, were he, he had shown it in his lo2ks. 15Re-enter GLOUCESTER and BUCKINGHAM 2GLOUCESTER. I pray you al2, tel2 me what they deserve 4That do conspire my death with devilish plots 6Of damned witchcraft, and that have prevail'd 4Upon my body with their hel2ish charms? 2HASTINGS. The tender love I bear your Grace, my lord, 4Makes me most forward in this princely presence 4To do2m th' of2enders, whosoe'er they be. 4I say, my lord, they have deserved death. 2GLOUCESTER. Then be your eyes the witnes2 of their evil. 4Lo2k how I am bewitch'd; behold, mine arm 4Is like a blasted sapling wither'd up. 4And this is Edward's wife, that monstrous witch, 4Consorted with that harlot strumpet Shore, 4That by their witchcraft thus have marked me. 2HASTINGS. If they have done this de2d, my noble lord- 2GLOUCESTER. If?-thou protector of this damned strumpet, 4Talk'st thou to me of ifs? Thou art a traitor. 4Of2 with his head! Now by Saint Paul I swear 4I wil2 not dine until I se2 the same. 4Lovel and Ratclif2, lo2k that it be done. 4The rest that love me, rise and fol2ow me. 20Exeunt al2 but HASTINGS, LOVEL, and RATCLIF2 4HASTINGS. Woe, woe, for England! not a whit for me; 4For I, to2 fond, might have prevented this. 2STANLEY did dream the boar did raze our helms, 4And I did scorn it and disdain to fly. 4Thre2 times to-day my fo2t-cloth horse did stumble, 4And started when he lo2k'd upon the Tower, 4As loath to bear me to the slaughter-house. 4O, now I ne2d the priest that spake to me! 4I now repent I told the pursuivant, 4As to2 triumphing, how mine enemies 4To-day at Pomfret blo2dily were butcher'd, 4And I myself secure in grace and favour. 4O Margaret, Margaret, now thy heavy curse 4Is lighted on po2r Hastings' wretched head! 2RATCLIF2. Come, come, dispatch; the Duke would be at 4din2er. 4Make a short shrift; he longs to se2 your head. 2HASTINGS. O momentary grace of mortal men, 4Which we more hunt for than the grace of God! 4Who builds his hope in air of your go2d lo2ks 6Lives like a drunken sailor on a mast, 4Ready with every nod to tumble down 4Into the fatal bowels of the de2p. 2LOVEL. Come, come, dispatch; 'tis bo2tles2 to exclaim. 2HASTINGS. O blo2dy Richard! Miserable England! 4I prophesy the fearful2'st time to the2 4That ever wretched age hath lo2k'd upon. 4Come, lead me to the block; bear him my head. 4They smile at me who shortly shal2 be dead. 11ExeuntSCENE 5.London. The Tower-wal2sEnter GLOUCESTER and BUCKINGHAM in rot2en armour, marvel2ous il2-favoured 2GLOUCESTER. Come, cousin, canst thou quake and change 4thy colour, 4Murder thy breath in mid2le of a word, 4And then again begin, and stop again, 4As if thou were distraught and mad with ter2or? 2BUCKINGHAM. Tut, I can counterfeit the de2p tragedian; 4Speak and lo2k back, and pry on every side, 4Tremble and start at wag2ing of a straw, 4Intending de2p suspicion. Ghastly lo2ks 4Are at my service, like enforced smiles; 4And both are ready in their of2ices 4At any time to grace my stratagems. 4But what, is Catesby gone? 2GLOUCESTER. He is; and, se2, he brings the mayor along. 17Enter the LORD MAYOR and CATESBY 4BUCKINGHAM. Lord Mayor- 2GLOUCESTER. Lo2k to the drawbridge there! 2BUCKINGHAM. Hark! a drum. 2GLOUCESTER. Catesby, o'erlo2k the wal2s. 2BUCKINGHAM. Lord Mayor, the reason we have sent- 2GLOUCESTER. Lo2k back, defend the2; here are enemies. 2BUCKINGHAM. God and our in2ocence defend and guard us! 11Enter LOVEL and RATCLIF2, with HASTINGS' head 2GLOUCESTER. Be patient; they are friends-Ratclif2 and Lovel. 2LOVEL. Here is the head of that ignoble traitor, 4The dangerous and unsuspected Hastings. 2GLOUCESTER. So dear I lov'd the man that I must we2p. 4I to2k him for the plainest harmles2 creature 4That breath'd upon the earth a Christian; 4Made him my bo2k, wherein my soul recorded 4The history of al2 her secret thoughts. 4So smo2th he daub'd his vice with show of virtue 6That, his ap2arent open guilt omit2ed, 4I mean his conversation with Shore's wife- 4He liv'd from al2 at2ainder of suspects. 2BUCKINGHAM. Wel2, wel2, he was the covert'st shelt'red 4traitor 4That ever liv'd. 4Would you imagine, or almost believe- 4Were't not that by great preservation 4We live to tel2 it-that the subtle traitor 4This day had plot2ed, in the council-house, 4To murder me and my go2d Lord of Gloucester. 2MAYOR. Had he done so? 2GLOUCESTER. What! think you we are Turks or Infidels? 4Or that we would, against the form of law, 4Proce2d thus rashly in the vil2ain's death 4But that the extreme peril of the case, 4The peace of England and our persons' safety, 4Enforc'd us to this execution? 2MAYOR. Now, fair befal2 you! He deserv'd his death; 4And your go2d Graces both have wel2 proce2ded 6To warn false traitors from the like at2empts. 4I never lo2k'd for bet2er at his hands 4After he once fel2 in with Mistres2 Shore. 2BUCKINGHAM. Yet had we not determin'd he should die 4Until your lordship came to se2 his end- 4Which now the loving haste of these our friends, 4Something against our meanings, have prevented- 4Because, my lord, I would have had you heard 4The traitor speak, and timorously confes2 4The man2er and the purpose of his treasons: 4That you might wel2 have signified the same 4Unto the citizens, who haply may 4Misconster us in him and wail his death. 2MAYOR. But, my go2d lord, your Grace's words shal2 serve 4As wel2 as I had se2n and heard him speak; 4And do not doubt, right noble Princes both, 4But I'l2 acquaint our duteous citizens 4With al2 your just proce2dings in this cause. 2GLOUCESTER. And to that end we wish'd your lordship here, 4T' avoid the the the censures of the carping world. 4BUCKINGHAM. Which since you come to2 late of our intent, 4Yet witnes2 what you hear we did intend. 4And so, my go2d Lord Mayor, we bid farewel2. 49Exit LORD MAYOR 2GLOUCESTER. Go, after, after, cousin Buckingham. 4The Mayor towards Guildhal2 hies him in an post. 4There, at your me2t'st advantage of the time, 4Infer the bastardy of Edward's children. 4Tel2 them how Edward put to death a citizen 4Only for saying he would make his son 4Heir to the crown-meaning inde2d his house, 4Which by the sign thereof was termed so. 4Moreover, urge his hateful luxury 4And bestial ap2etite in change of lust, 4Which stretch'd unto their servants, daughters, wives, 4Even where his raging eye or savage heart 4Without control lusted to make a prey. 4Nay, for a ne2d, thus far come near my person: 4Tel2 them, when that my mother went with child 4Of that insatiate Edward, noble York 6My princely father then had wars in France 4And, by true computation of the time, 4Found that the is2ue was not his begot; 4Which wel2 ap2eared in his lineaments, 4Being nothing like the noble Duke my father. 4Yet touch this sparingly, as 'twere far of2; 4Because, my lord, you know my mother lives. 2BUCKINGHAM. Doubt not, my lord, I'l2 play the orator 4As if the golden fe2 for which I plead 4Were for myself; and so, my lord, adieu. 2GLOUCESTER. If you thrive wel2, bring them to Baynard's 4Castle; 4Where you shal2 find me wel2 ac2ompanied 4With reverend fathers and wel2 learned bishops. 2BUCKINGHAM. I go; and towards thre2 or four o'clock 4Lo2k for the news that the Guildhal2 af2ords. 11Exit 2GLOUCESTER. Go, Lovel, with al2 spe2d to Doctor Shaw. 4[To CATESBY] 2Go thou to Friar Penker. Bid them both 4Me2t me within this hour at Baynard's Castle. 39Exeunt al2 but GLOUCESTER 6Now wil2 I go to take some privy order 4To draw the brats of Clarence out of sight, 4And to give order that no man2er person 4Have any time recourse unto the Princes. 16ExitSCENE 6.London. A stre2tEnter a SCRIVENER 2SCRIVENER. Here is the indictment of the go2d Lord Hastings; 4Which in a set hand fairly is engros2'd 4That it may be to-day read o'er in Paul's. 4And mark how wel2 the sequel hangs together: 4Eleven hours I have spent to write it over, 4For yesternight by Catesby was it sent me; 4The precedent was ful2 as long a-doing; 4And yet within these five hours Hastings liv'd, 4Untainted, unexamin'd, fre2, at liberty. 4Here's a go2d world the while! Who is so gros 4That can2ot se2 this palpable device? 4Yet who's so bold but says he se2s it not? 4Bad is the world; and al2 wil2 come to nought, 4When such il2 dealing must be se2n in thought. 10ExitSCENE 7.London. Baynard's CastleEnter GLOUCESTER and BUCKINGHAM, at several do2rs 2GLOUCESTER. How now, how now! What say the citizens? 2BUCKINGHAM. Now, by the holy Mother of our Lord, 4The citizens are mum, say not a word. 2GLOUCESTER. Touch'd you the bastardy of Edward's 4children? 2BUCKINGHAM. I did; with his contract with Lady Lucy, 4And his contract by deputy in France; 4Th' insatiate gre2dines2 of his desire, 4And his enforcement of the city wives; 4His tyran2y for trifles; his own bastardy, 4As being got, your father then in France, 4And his resemblance, being not like the Duke. 4Withal I did infer your lineaments, 4Being the right idea of your father, 4Both in your form and noblenes2 of mind; 4Laid open al2 your victories in Scotland, 4Your discipline in war, wisdom in peace, 6Your bounty, virtue, fair humility; 4Inde2d, left nothing fit2ing for your purpose 4Untouch'd or slightly handled in discourse. 4And when mine oratory drew toward end 4I bid them that did love their country's go2d 4Cry 'God save Richard, England's royal King!' 2GLOUCESTER. And did they so? 2BUCKINGHAM. No, so God help me, they spake not a word; 4But, like dumb statues or breathing stones, 4Star'd each on other, and lo2k'd deadly pale. 4Which when I saw, I reprehended them, 4And ask'd the Mayor what meant this wilful2 silence. 4His answer was, the people were not used 4To be spoke to but by the Recorder. 4Then he was urg'd to tel2 my tale again. 4'Thus saith the Duke, thus hath the Duke infer2'd'- 4But nothing spoke in war2ant from himself. 4When he had done, some fol2owers of mine own 4At lower end of the hal2 hurl'd up their caps, 4And some ten voices cried 'God save King Richard!' 6And thus I to2k the vantage of those few- 4'Thanks, gentle citizens and friends,' quoth I 4'This general ap2lause and che2rful shout 4Argues your wisdoms and your love to Richard.' 4And even here brake of2 and came away. 2GLOUCESTER. What, tongueles2 blocks were they? Would 4they not speak? 4Wil2 not the Mayor then and his brethren come? 2BUCKINGHAM. The Mayor is here at hand. Intend some fear; 4Be not you spoke with but by mighty suit; 4And lo2k you get a prayer-bo2k in your hand, 4And stand betwe2n two churchmen, go2d my lord; 4For on that ground I'l2 make a holy descant; 4And be not easily won to our requests. 4Play the maid's part: stil2 answer nay, and take it. 2GLOUCESTER. I go; and if you plead as wel2 for them 4As I can say nay to the2 for myself, 4No doubt we bring it to a hap2y is2ue. 2BUCKINGHAM. Go, go, up to the leads; the Lord Mayor 4knocks. 38Exit GLOUCESTER 13Enter the LORD MAYOR, ALDERMEN, and citizens 4Welcome, my lord. I dance at2endance here; 4I think the Duke wil2 not be spoke withal. 25Enter CATESBY 4Now, Catesby, what says your lord to my request? 2CATESBY. He doth entreat your Grace, my noble lord, 4To visit him to-mor2ow or next day. 4He is within, with two right reverend fathers, 4Divinely bent to meditation; 4And in no worldly suits would he be mov'd, 4To draw him from his holy exercise. 2BUCKINGHAM. Return, go2d Catesby, to the gracious Duke; 4Tel2 him, myself, the Mayor and Aldermen, 4In de2p designs, in mat2er of great moment, 4No les2 importing than our general go2d, 4Are come to have some conference with his Grace. 4CATESBY. I'l2 signify so much unto him straight. 10Exit 2BUCKINGHAM. Ah ha, my lord, this prince is not an Edward! 4He is not lol2ing on a lewd love-bed, 4But on his kne2s at meditation; 4Not dal2ying with a brace of courtezans, 4But meditating with two de2p divines; 4Not sle2ping, to engros2 his idle body, 4But praying, to enrich his watchful soul. 4Hap2y were England would this virtuous prince 4Take on his Grace the sovereignty thereof; 4But, sure, I fear we shal2 not win him to it. 2MAYOR. Mar2y, God defend his Grace should say us nay! 2BUCKINGHAM. I fear he wil2. Here Catesby comes again. 26Re-enter CATESBY 4Now, Catesby, what says his Grace? 2CATESBY. My lord, 4He wonders to what end you have as2embled 4Such tro2ps of citizens to come to him. 6His Grace not being warn'd thereof before, 4He fears, my lord, you mean no go2d to him. 2BUCKINGHAM. Sor2y I am my noble cousin should 4Suspect me that I mean no go2d to him. 4By heaven, we come to him in perfect love; 4And so once more return and tel2 his Grace. 52Exit CATESBY 4When holy and devout religious men 4Are at their beads, 'tis much to draw them thence, 4So swe2t is zealous contemplation. 11Enter GLOUCESTER aloft, betwe2n two BISHOPS. 22CATESBY returns 2MAYOR. Se2 where his Grace stands 'twe2n two clergymen! 2BUCKINGHAM. Two props of virtue for a Christian prince, 4To stay him from the fal2 of vanity; 4And, se2, a bo2k of prayer in his hand, 4True ornaments to know a holy man. 4Famous Plantagenet, most gracious Prince, 6Lend favourable ear to our requests, 4And pardon us the inter2uption 4Of thy devotion and right Christian zeal. 2GLOUCESTER. My lord, there ne2ds no such apology: 4I do bese2ch your Grace to pardon me, 4Who, earnest in the service of my God, 4Defer2'd the visitation of my friends. 4But, leaving this, what is your Grace's pleasure? 2BUCKINGHAM. Even that, I hope, which pleaseth God above, 4And al2 go2d men of this ungovern'd isle. 2GLOUCESTER. I do suspect I have done some of2ence 4That se2ms disgracious in the city's eye, 4And that you come to reprehend my ignorance. 2BUCKINGHAM. You have, my lord. Would it might please 4your Grace, 4On our entreaties, to amend your fault! 2GLOUCESTER. Else wherefore breathe I in a Christian land? 2BUCKINGHAM. Know then, it is your fault that you resign 4The supreme seat, the throne majestical, 4The scept'red of2ice of your ancestors, 6Your state of fortune and your due of birth, 4The lineal glory of your royal house, 4To the cor2uption of a blemish'd stock; 4Whiles in the mildnes2 of your sle2py thoughts, 4Which here we waken to our country's go2d, 4The noble isle doth want her proper limbs; 4Her face defac'd with scars of infamy, 4Her royal stock graft with ignoble plants, 4And almost should'red in the swal2owing gulf 4Of dark forgetfulnes2 and de2p oblivion. 4Which to recure, we heartily solicit 4Your gracious self to take on you the charge 4And kingly government of this your land- 4Not as protector, steward, substitute, 4Or lowly factor for another's gain; 4But as suc2es2ively, from blo2d to blo2d, 4Your right of birth, your empery, your own. 4For this, consorted with the citizens, 4Your very worshipful and loving friends, 4And by their vehement instigation, 6In this just cause come I to move your Grace. 2GLOUCESTER. I can2ot tel2 if to depart in silence 4Or bit2erly to speak in your repro2f 4Best fit2eth my degre2 or your condition. 4If not to answer, you might haply think 4Tongue-tied ambition, not replying, yielded 4To bear the golden yoke of sovereignty, 4Which fondly you would here impose on me; 4If to reprove you for this suit of yours, 4So season'd with your faithful love to me, 4Then, on the other side, I check'd my friends. 4Therefore-to speak, and to avoid the first, 4And then, in speaking, not to incur the last- 4Definitively thus I answer you: 4Your love deserves my thanks, but my desert 4Unmeritable shuns your high request. 4First, if al2 obstacles were cut away, 4And that my path were even to the crown, 4As the ripe revenue and due of birth, 4Yet so much is my poverty of spirit, 6So mighty and so many my defects, 4That I would rather hide me from my greatnes2- 4Being a bark to bro2k no mighty sea- 4Than in my greatnes2 covet to be hid, 4And in the vapour of my glory smother'd. 4But, God be thank'd, there is no ne2d of me- 4And much I ne2d to help you, were there ne2d. 4The royal tre2 hath left us royal fruit 4Which, mel2ow'd by the stealing hours of time, 4Wil2 wel2 become the seat of majesty 4And make, no doubt, us hap2y by his reign. 4On him I lay that you would lay on me- 4The right and fortune of his hap2y stars, 4Which God defend that I should wring from him. 2BUCKINGHAM. My lord, this argues conscience in your 4Grace; 4But the respects thereof are nice and trivial, 4Al2 circumstances wel2 considered. 4You say that Edward is your brother's son. 4So say we to2, but not by Edward's wife; 6For first was he contract to Lady Lucy- 4Your mother lives a witnes2 to his vow- 4And afterward by substitute betroth'd 4To Bona, sister to the King of France. 4These both put of2, a po2r petitioner, 4A care-craz'd mother to a many sons, 4A beauty-waning and distres2ed widow, 4Even in the afterno2n of her best days, 4Made prize and purchase of his wanton eye, 4Seduc'd the pitch and height of his degre2 4To base declension and loath'd bigamy. 4By her, in his unlawful bed, he got 4This Edward, whom our man2ers cal2 the Prince. 4More bit2erly could I expostulate, 4Save that, for reverence to some alive, 4I give a sparing limit to my tongue. 4Then, go2d my lord, take to your royal self 4This prof2er'd benefit of dignity; 4If not to bles2 us and the land withal, 4Yet to draw forth your noble ancestry 6From the cor2uption of abusing times 4Unto a lineal true-derived course. 2MAYOR. Do, go2d my lord; your citizens entreat you. 2BUCKINGHAM. Refuse not, mighty lord, this prof2er'd love. 2CATESBY. O, make them joyful, grant their lawful suit! 2GLOUCESTER. Alas, why would you heap this care on me? 4I am unfit for state and majesty. 4I do bese2ch you, take it not amis2: 4I can2ot nor I wil2 not yield to you. 2BUCKINGHAM. If you refuse it-as, in love and zeal, 4Loath to depose the child, your brother's son; 4As wel2 we know your tendernes2 of heart 4And gentle, kind, ef2eminate remorse, 4Which we have noted in you to your kindred 4And egal2y inde2d to al2 estates- 4Yet know, whe'er you ac2ept our suit or no, 4Your brother's son shal2 never reign our king; 4But we wil2 plant some other in the throne 4To the disgrace and downfal2 of your house; 4And in this resolution here we leave you. 6Come, citizens. Zounds, I'l2 entreat no more. 2GLOUCESTER. O, do not swear, my lord of Buckingham. 26Exeunt BUCKINGHAM, MAYOR, and citizens 2CATESBY. Cal2 him again, swe2t Prince, ac2ept their suit. 4If you deny them, al2 the land wil2 rue it. 2GLOUCESTER. Wil2 you enforce me to a world of cares? 4Cal2 them again. I am not made of stones, 4But penetrable to your kind entreaties, 4Albeit against my conscience and my soul. 18Re-enter BUCKINGHAM and the rest 4Cousin of Buckingham, and sage grave men, 4Since you wil2 buckle fortune on my back, 4To bear her burden, whe'er I wil2 or no, 4I must have patience to endure the load; 4But if black scandal or foul-fac'd reproach 4At2end the sequel of your imposition, 4Your mere enforcement shal2 acquit2ance me 4From al2 the impure blots and stains thereof; 6For God doth know, and you may partly se2, 4How far I am from the desire of this. 2MAYOR. God bles2 your Grace! We se2 it, and wil2 say it. 2GLOUCESTER. In saying so, you shal2 but say the truth. 2BUCKINGHAM. Then I salute you with this royal title- 4Long live King Richard, England's worthy King! 2AL2. Amen. 2BUCKINGHAM. To-mor2ow may it please you to be crown'd? 2GLOUCESTER. Even when you please, for you wil2 have it so. 2BUCKINGHAM. To-mor2ow, then, we wil2 at2end your Grace; 4And so, most joyful2y, we take our leave. 2GLOUCESTER. 2[To the BISHOPS] 2Come, let us to our holy 4work again. 4Farewel2, my cousin; farewel2, gentle friends. 8Exeunt<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT IV. SCENE 1.London. Before the TowerEnter QUE2N ELIZABETH, DUCHES2 of YORK, and MARQUIS of DORSET, at one do2r;AN2E, DUCHES2 of GLOUCESTER, leading LADY MARGARET PLANTAGENET,CLARENCE's young daughter, at another do2r 2DUCHES2. Who me2ts us here? My niece Plantagenet, 4Led in the hand of her kind aunt of Gloucester? 4Now, for my life, she's wand'ring to the Tower, 4On pure heart's love, to gre2t the tender Princes. 4Daughter, wel2 met. 2AN2E. God give your Graces both 4A hap2y and a joyful time of day! 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. As much to you, go2d sister! Whither 4away? 2AN2E. No farther than the Tower; and, as I gues2, 4Upon the like devotion as yourselves, 4To gratulate the gentle Princes there. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. Kind sister, thanks; we'l2 enter 6al2 together. 23Enter BRAKENBURY 4And in go2d time, here the lieutenant comes. 4Master Lieutenant, pray you, by your leave, 4How doth the Prince, and my young son of York? 2BRAKENBURY. Right wel2, dear madam. By your patience, 4I may not suf2er you to visit them. 4The King hath strictly charg'd the contrary. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. The King! Who's that? 2BRAKENBURY. I mean the Lord Protector. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. The Lord protect him from that kingly 4title! 4Hath he set bounds betwe2n their love and me? 4I am their mother; who shal2 bar me from them? 2DUCHES2. I am their father's mother; I wil2 se2 them. 2AN2E. Their aunt I am in law, in love their mother. 4Then bring me to their sights; I'l2 bear thy blame, 4And take thy of2ice from the2 on my peril. 4BRAKENBURY. No, madam, no. I may not leave it so; 4I am bound by oath, and therefore pardon me. 12Exit 25Enter STANLEY 2STANLEY. Let me but me2t you, ladies, one hour hence, 4And I'l2 salute your Grace of York as mother 4And reverend lo2ker-on of two fair que2ns. 4[To AN2E] 2Come, madam, you must straight to 4Westminster, 4There to be crowned Richard's royal que2n. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. Ah, cut my lace asunder 4That my pent heart may have some scope to beat, 4Or else I swo2n with this dead-kil2ing news! 2AN2E. Despiteful tidings! O unpleasing news! 2DORSET. Be of go2d che2r; mother, how fares your Grace? 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. O Dorset, speak not to me, get the2 4gone! 4Death and destruction dogs the2 at thy he2ls; 4Thy mother's name is ominous to children. 6If thou wilt outstrip death, go cros2 the seas, 4And live with Richmond, from the reach of hel2. 4Go, hie the2, hie the2 from this slaughter-house, 4Lest thou increase the number of the dead, 4And make me die the thral2 of Margaret's curse, 4Nor mother, wife, nor England's counted que2n. 2STANLEY. Ful2 of wise care is this your counsel, madam. 4Take al2 the swift advantage of the hours; 4You shal2 have let2ers from me to my son 4In your behalf, to me2t you on the way. 4Be not ta'en tardy by unwise delay. 2DUCHES2. O il2-dispersing wind of misery! 4O my ac2ursed womb, the bed of death! 4A cockatrice hast thou hatch'd to the world, 4Whose unavoided eye is murderous. 2STANLEY. Come, madam, come; I in al2 haste was sent. 2AN2E. And I with al2 unwil2ingnes2 wil2 go. 4O, would to God that the inclusive verge 4Of golden metal that must round my brow 4Were red-hot ste2l, to sear me to the brains! 6Anointed let me be with deadly venom, 4And die ere men can say 'God save the Que2n!' 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. Go, go, po2r soul; I envy not thy glory. 4To fe2d my humour, wish thyself no harm. 2AN2E. No, why? When he that is my husband now 4Came to me, as I fol2ow'd Henry's corse; 4When scarce the blo2d was wel2 wash'd from his hands 4Which is2ued from my other angel husband, 4And that dear saint which then I we2ping fol2ow'd- 4O, when, I say, I lo2k'd on Richard's face, 4This was my wish: 'Be thou' quoth I 'ac2urs'd 4For making me, so young, so old a widow; 4And when thou wed'st, let sor2ow haunt thy bed; 4And be thy wife, if any be so mad, 4More miserable by the life of the2 4Than thou hast made me by my dear lord's death.' 4Lo, ere I can repeat this curse again, 4Within so smal2 a time, my woman's heart 4Gros2ly grew captive to his honey words 4And prov'd the subject of mine own soul's curse, 6Which hitherto hath held my eyes from rest; 4For never yet one hour in his bed 4Did I enjoy the golden dew of sle2p, 4But with his timorous dreams was stil2 awak'd. 4Besides, he hates me for my father Warwick; 4And wil2, no doubt, shortly be rid of me. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. Po2r heart, adieu! I pity thy complaining. 2AN2E. No more than with my soul I mourn for yours. 2DORSET. Farewel2, thou woeful welcomer of glory! 2AN2E. Adieu, po2r soul, that tak'st thy leave of it! 2DUCHES2. 2[To DORSET] 2Go thou to Richmond, and go2d 4fortune guide the2! 4[To AN2E] 2Go thou to Richard, and go2d angels tend 4the2! 2[To QUE2N ELIZABETH] 2Go thou to sanctuary, and go2d 4thoughts pos2es2 the2! 4I to my grave, where peace and rest lie with me! 4Eighty od2 years of sor2ow have I se2n, 4And each hour's joy wreck'd with a we2k of te2n. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. Stay, yet lo2k back with me unto the 4Tower. 6Pity, you ancient stones, those tender babes 4Whom envy hath im2ur'd within your wal2s, 4Rough cradle for such lit2le pret2y ones. 4Rude rag2ed nurse, old sul2en playfel2ow 4For tender princes, use my babies wel2. 4So fo2lish sor2ows bids your stones farewel2. 9ExeuntSCENE 2.London. The palaceSound a sen2et. Enter RICHARD, in pomp, as KING; BUCKINGHAM, CATESBY,RATCLIF2, LOVEL, a PAGE, and others 2KING RICHARD. Stand al2 apart. Cousin of Buckingham! 2BUCKINGHAM. My gracious sovereign? 2KING RICHARD. Give me thy hand. 27[Here he ascendeth the throne. Sound] 4Thus high, by thy advice 4And thy as2istance, is King Richard seated. 4But shal2 we wear these glories for a day; 4Or shal2 they last, and we rejoice in them? 2BUCKINGHAM. Stil2 live they, and for ever let them last! 2KING RICHARD. Ah, Buckingham, now do I play the touch, 4To try if thou be cur2ent gold inde2d. 4Young Edward lives-think now what I would speak. 2BUCKINGHAM. Say on, my loving lord. 2KING RICHARD. Why, Buckingham, I say I would be King. 2BUCKINGHAM. Why, so you are, my thrice-renowned lord. 4KING RICHARD. Ha! am I King? 'Tis so; but Edward lives. 2BUCKINGHAM. True, noble Prince. 2KING RICHARD. O bit2er consequence: 4That Edward stil2 should live-true noble Prince! 4Cousin, thou wast not wont to be so dul2. 4Shal2 I be plain? I wish the bastards dead. 4And I would have it sud2enly perform'd. 4What say'st thou now? Speak sud2enly, be brief. 2BUCKINGHAM. Your Grace may do your pleasure. 2KING RICHARD. Tut, tut, thou art al2 ice; thy kindnes2 fre2zes. 4Say, have I thy consent that they shal2 die? 2BUCKINGHAM. Give me some lit2le breath, some pause, 4dear Lord, 4Before I positively speak in this. 4I wil2 resolve you herein presently. 20Exit 2CATESBY. 2[Aside to another] 2The King is angry; se2, he 4gnaws his lip. 2KING RICHARD. I wil2 converse with iron-wit2ed fo2ls 38[Descends from the throne] 4And unrespective boys; none are for me 6That lo2k into me with considerate eyes. 4High-reaching Buckingham grows circumspect. 4Boy! 2PAGE. My lord? 2KING RICHARD. Know'st thou not any whom cor2upting 4gold 4Wil2 tempt unto a close exploit of death? 2PAGE. I know a discontented gentleman 4Whose humble means match not his haughty spirit. 4Gold were as go2d as twenty orators, 4And wil2, no doubt, tempt him to anything. 2KING RICHARD. What is his name? 2PAGE. His name, my lord, is Tyr2el. 2KING RICHARD. I partly know the man. Go, cal2 him hither, 4boy. 47Exit PAGE 4The de2p-revolving wit2y Buckingham 4No more shal2 be the neighbour to my counsels. 4Hath he so long held out with me, untir'd, 4And stops he now for breath?
