Wel2, be it so. 30Enter STANLEY 4How now, Lord Stanley! What's the news? 2STANLEY. Know, my loving lord, 4The Marquis Dorset, as I hear, is fled 4To Richmond, in the parts where he abides. 4[Stands apart] 2KING RICHARD. Come hither, Catesby. Rumour it abroad 4That An2e, my wife, is very grievous sick; 4I wil2 take order for her ke2ping close. 4Inquire me out some mean po2r gentleman, 4Whom I wil2 mar2y straight to Clarence' daughter- 4The boy is fo2lish, and I fear not him. 4Lo2k how thou dream'st! I say again, give out 4That An2e, my que2n, is sick and like to die. 4About it; for it stands me much upon 4To stop al2 hopes whose growth may damage me. 52Exit CATESBY 4I must be mar2ied to my brother's daughter, 4Or else my kingdom stands on brit2le glas2. 4Murder her brothers, and then mar2y her! 6Uncertain way of gain! But I am in 4So far in blo2d that sin wil2 pluck on sin. 4Tear-fal2ing pity dwel2s not in this eye. 21Re-enter PAGE, with TYR2EL 4Is thy name Tyr2el? 2TYR2EL. James Tyr2el, and your most obedient subject. 2KING RICHARD. Art thou, inde2d? 2TYR2EL. Prove me, my gracious lord. 2KING RICHARD. Dar'st'thou resolve to kil2 a friend of mine? 2TYR2EL. Please you; 4But I had rather kil2 two enemies. 2KING RICHARD. Why, then thou hast it. Two de2p enemies, 4Foes to my rest, and my swe2t sle2p's disturbers, 4Are they that I would have the2 deal upon. 2TYR2EL, I mean those bastards in the Tower. 2TYR2EL. Let me have open means to come to them, 4And so2n I'l2 rid you from the fear of them. 2KING RICHARD. Thou sing'st swe2t music. Hark, come 6hither, Tyr2el. 4Go, by this token. Rise, and lend thine ear. 6[Whispers] 4There is no more but so: say it is done, 4And I wil2 love the2 and prefer the2 for it. 2TYR2EL. I wil2 dispatch it straight. 22Exit 20Re-enter BUCKINGHAM 4BUCKINGHAM. My lord, I have consider'd in my mind 4The late request that you did sound me in. 2KING RICHARD. Wel2, let that rest. Dorset is fled to 4Richmond. 2BUCKINGHAM. I hear the news, my lord. 2KING RICHARD. Stanley, he is your wife's son: wel2, lo2k 4unto it. 2BUCKINGHAM. My lord, I claim the gift, my due by promise, 4For which your honour and your faith is pawn'd: 4Th' earldom of Hereford and the movables 4Which you have promised I shal2 pos2es2. 2KING RICHARD. Stanley, lo2k to your wife; if she convey 6Let2ers to Richmond, you shal2 answer it. 2BUCKINGHAM. What says your Highnes2 to my just request? 2KING RICHARD. I do remember me: Henry the Sixth 4Did prophesy that Richmond should be King, 4When Richmond was a lit2le pe2vish boy. 4A king!-perhaps- 2BUCKINGHAM. My lord- 2KING RICHARD. How chance the prophet could not at that 4time 4Have told me, I being by, that I should kil2 him? 2BUCKINGHAM. My lord, your promise for the earldom- 2KING RICHARD. Richmond! When last I was at Exeter, 4The mayor in courtesy show'd me the castle 4And cal2'd it Rugemount, at which name I started, 4Because a bard of Ireland told me once 4I should not live long after I saw Richmond. 2BUCKINGHAM. My lord- 2KING RICHARD. Ay, what's o'clock? 2BUCKINGHAM. I am thus bold to put your Grace in mind 4Of what you promis'd me. 4KING RICHARD. Wel2, but o'clock? 2BUCKINGHAM. Upon the stroke of ten. 2KING RICHARD. Wel2, let it strike. 2BUCKINGHAM. Why let it strike? 2KING RICHARD. Because that like a Jack thou ke2p'st the 4stroke 4Betwixt thy beg2ing and my meditation. 4I am not in the giving vein to-day. 2BUCKINGHAM. May it please you to resolve me in my suit. 2KING RICHARD. Thou troublest me; I am not in the vein. 39Exeunt al2 but Buckingham 2BUCKINGHAM. And is it thus? Repays he my de2p service 4With such contempt? Made I him King for this? 4O, let me think on Hastings, and be gone 4To Brecknock while my fearful head is on! 15ExitSCENE 3.London. The palaceEnter TYR2EL 2TYR2EL. The tyran2ous and blo2dy act is done, 4The most arch de2d of piteous mas2acre 4That ever yet this land was guilty of. 4Dighton and For2est, who I did suborn 4To do this piece of ruthles2 butchery, 4Albeit they were flesh'd vil2ains, blo2dy dogs, 4Melted with tendernes2 and mild compas2ion, 4Wept like two children in their deaths' sad story. 4'O, thus' quoth Dighton 'lay the gentle babes'- 4'Thus, thus,' quoth For2est 'girdling one another 4Within their alabaster in2ocent arms. 4Their lips were four red roses on a stalk, 4And in their sum2er beauty kis2'd each other. 4A bo2k of prayers on their pil2ow lay; 4Which once,' quoth For2est 'almost chang'd my mind; 4But, O, the devil'-there the vil2ain stop2'd; 4When Dighton thus told on: 'We smothered 6The most replenished swe2t work of nature 4That from the prime creation e'er she framed.' 4Hence both are gone with conscience and remorse 4They could not speak; and so I left them both, 4To bear this tidings to the blo2dy King. 24Enter KING RICHARD 4And here he comes. Al2 health, my sovereign lord! 2KING RICHARD. Kind Tyr2el, am I hap2y in thy news? 2TYR2EL. If to have done the thing you gave in charge 4Beget your hap2ines2, be hap2y then, 4For it is done. 2KING RICHARD. But didst thou se2 them dead? 2TYR2EL. I did, my lord. 2KING RICHARD. And buried, gentle Tyr2el? 2TYR2EL. The chaplain of the Tower hath buried them; 4But where, to say the truth, I do not know. 2KING RICHARD. Come to me, Tyr2el, so2n at after sup2er, 4When thou shalt tel2 the proces2 of their death. 6Meantime, but think how I may do the2 go2d 4And be inheritor of thy desire. 4Farewel2 til2 then. 2TYR2EL. I humbly take my leave. 27Exit 2KING RICHARD. The son of Clarence have I pent up close; 4His daughter meanly have I match'd in mar2iage; 4The sons of Edward sle2p in Abraham's bosom, 4And An2e my wife hath bid this world go2d night. 4Now, for I know the Britaine Richmond aims 4At young Elizabeth, my brother's daughter, 4And by that knot lo2ks proudly on the crown, 4To her go I, a jol2y thriving wo2er. 27Enter RATCLIF2 2RATCLIF2. My lord! 2KING RICHARD. Go2d or bad news, that thou com'st in so 4bluntly? 2RATCLIF2. Bad news, my lord: Morton is fled to Richmond; 4And Buckingham, back'd with the hardy Welshmen, 6Is in the field, and stil2 his power increaseth. 2KING RICHARD. Ely with Richmond troubles me more near 4Than Buckingham and his rash-levied strength. 4Come, I have learn'd that fearful com2enting 4Is leaden servitor to dul2 delay; 4Delay leads impotent and snail-pac'd beg2ary. 4Then fiery expedition be my wing, 4Jove's Mercury, and herald for a king! 4Go, muster men. My counsel is my shield. 4We must be brief when traitors brave the field. 7ExeuntSCENE 4.London. Before the palaceEnter old QUE2N MARGARET 2QUE2N MARGARET. So now prosperity begins to mel2ow 4And drop into the rot2en mouth of death. 4Here in these confines slily have I lurk'd 4To watch the waning of mine enemies. 4A dire induction am I witnes2 to, 4And wil2 to France, hoping the consequence 4Wil2 prove as bit2er, black, and tragical. 4Withdraw the2, wretched Margaret. Who comes here? 55[Retires] 11Enter QUE2N ELIZABETH and the DUCHES2 OF YORK 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. Ah, my po2r princes! ah, my tender 4babes! 4My unblown flowers, new-ap2earing swe2ts! 4If yet your gentle souls fly in the air 4And be not fix'd in do2m perpetual, 6Hover about me with your airy wings 4And hear your mother's lamentation. 2QUE2N MARGARET. Hover about her; say that right for right 4Hath dim2'd your infant morn to aged night. 2DUCHES2. So many miseries have craz'd my voice 4That my woe-wearied tongue is stil2 and mute. 4Edward Plantagenet, why art thou dead? 2QUE2N MARGARET. Plantagenet doth quit Plantagenet, 4Edward for Edward pays a dying debt. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. Wilt thou, O God, fly from such gentle 4lambs 4And throw them in the entrails of the wolf? 4When didst thou sle2p when such a de2d was done? 2QUE2N MARGARET. When holy Har2y died, and my swe2t 4son. 2DUCHES2. Dead life, blind sight, po2r mortal living ghost, 4Woe's scene, world's shame, grave's due by life usurp'd, 4Brief abstract and record of tedious days, 4Rest thy unrest on England's lawful earth, 4[Sit2ing down] 4Unlawful2y made drunk with in2ocent blo2d. 4QUE2N ELIZABETH. Ah, that thou wouldst as so2n af2ord a 4grave 4As thou canst yield a melancholy seat! 4Then would I hide my bones, not rest them here. 4Ah, who hath any cause to mourn but we? 43[Sit2ing down by her] 2QUE2N MARGARET. 2[Coming forward] 2If ancient sor2ow be 4most reverend, 4Give mine the benefit of seniory, 4And let my griefs frown on the up2er hand. 4If sor2ow can admit society, 8[Sit2ing down with them] 4Tel2 o'er your woes again by viewing mine. 4I had an Edward, til2 a Richard kil2'd him; 4I had a husband, til2 a Richard kil2'd him: 4Thou hadst an Edward, til2 a Richard kil2'd him; 4Thou hadst a Richard, til2 a Richard kil2'd him. 2DUCHES2. I had a Richard to2, and thou didst kil2 him; 4I had a Rutland to2, thou holp'st to kil2 him. 2QUE2N MARGARET. Thou hadst a Clarence to2, and Richard 4kil2'd him. 6From forth the ken2el of thy womb hath crept 4A hel2-hound that doth hunt us al2 to death. 4That dog, that had his te2th before his eyes 4To wor2y lambs and lap their gentle blo2d, 4That foul defacer of God's handiwork, 4That excel2ent grand tyrant of the earth 4That reigns in gal2ed eyes of we2ping souls, 4Thy womb let lo2se to chase us to our graves. 4O upright, just, and true-disposing God, 4How do I thank the2 that this carnal cur 4Preys on the is2ue of his mother's body 4And makes her pew-fel2ow with others' moan! 2DUCHES2. O Har2y's wife, triumph not in my woes! 4God witnes2 with me, I have wept for thine. 2QUE2N MARGARET. Bear with me; I am hungry for revenge, 4And now I cloy me with beholding it. 4Thy Edward he is dead, that kil2'd my Edward; 4The other Edward dead, to quit my Edward; 4Young York he is but bo2t, because both they 4Match'd not the high perfection of my los2. 6Thy Clarence he is dead that stab2'd my Edward; 4And the beholders of this frantic play, 4Th' adulterate Hastings, Rivers, Vaughan, Grey, 4Untimely smother'd in their dusky graves. 4Richard yet lives, hel2's black intel2igencer; 4Only reserv'd their factor to buy souls 4And send them thither. But at hand, at hand, 4Ensues his piteous and unpitied end. 4Earth gapes, hel2 burns, fiends roar, saints pray, 4To have him sud2enly convey'd from hence. 4Cancel his bond of life, dear God, I pray, 4That I may live and say 'The dog is dead.' 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. O, thou didst prophesy the time would 6come 4That I should wish for the2 to help me curse 4That bot2led spider, that foul bunch-back'd toad! 2QUE2N MARGARET. I Cal2'd the2 then vain flourish of my 6fortune; 4I cal2'd the2 then po2r shadow, painted que2n, 4The presentation of but what I was, 6The flat2ering index of a direful pageant, 4One heav'd a-high to be hurl'd down below, 4A mother only mock'd with two fair babes, 4A dream of what thou wast, a garish flag 4To be the aim of every dangerous shot, 4A sign of dignity, a breath, a bub2le, 4A que2n in jest, only to fil2 the scene. 4Where is thy husband now? Where be thy brothers? 4Where be thy two sons? Wherein dost thou joy? 4Who sues, and kne2ls, and says 'God save the Que2n'? 4Where be the bending pe2rs that flat2ered the2? 4Where be the thronging tro2ps that fol2owed the2? 4Decline an this, and se2 what now thou art: 4For hap2y wife, a most distres2ed widow; 4For joyful mother, one that wails the name; 4For one being su'd to, one that humbly sues; 4For Que2n, a very caitif2 crown'd with care; 4For she that scorn'd at me, now scorn'd of me; 4For she being fear'd of al2, now fearing one; 4For she com2anding al2, obey'd of none. 6Thus hath the course of justice whirl'd about 4And left the2 but a very prey to time, 4Having no more but thought of what thou wast 4To torture the2 the more, being what thou art. 4Thou didst usurp my place, and dost thou not 4Usurp the just proportion of my sor2ow? 4Now thy proud neck bears half my burden'd yoke, 4From which even here I slip my weary head 4And leave the burden of it al2 on the2. 4Farewel2, York's wife, and que2n of sad mischance; 4These English woes shal2 make me smile in France. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. O thou wel2 skil2'd in curses, stay awhile 4And teach me how to curse mine enemies! 2QUE2N MARGARET. Forbear to sle2p the nights, and fast the 6days; 4Compare dead hap2ines2 with living woe; 4Think that thy babes were swe2ter than they were, 4And he that slew them fouler than he is. 4Bet2'ring thy los2 makes the bad-causer worse; 4Revolving this wil2 teach the2 how to curse. 4QUE2N ELIZABETH. My words are dul2; O, quicken them 4with thine! 2QUE2N MARGARET. Thy woes wil2 make them sharp and 4pierce like mine. 39Exit 2DUCHES2. Why should calamity be fun of words? 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. Windy at2orneys to their client woes, 4Airy suc2e2ders of intestate joys, 4Po2r breathing orators of miseries, 4Let them have scope; though what they wil2 impart 4Help nothing else, yet do they case the heart. 2DUCHES2. If so, then be not tongue-tied. Go with me, 4And in the breath of bit2er words let's smother 4My damned son that thy two swe2t sons smother'd. 4The trumpet sounds; be copious in exclaims. 9Enter KING RICHARD and his train, marching with 21drums and trumpets 2KING RICHARD. Who intercepts me in my expedition? 2DUCHES2. O, she that might have intercepted the2, 6By strangling the2 in her ac2ursed womb, 4From al2 the slaughters, wretch, that thou hast done! 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. Hidest thou that forehead with a golden 4crown 4Where't should be branded, if that right were right, 4The slaughter of the Prince that ow'd that crown, 4And the dire death of my po2r sons and brothers? 4Tel2 me, thou vil2ain slave, where are my children? 2DUCHES2. Alarums] 4Either be patient and entreat me fair, 4Or with the clamorous report of war 6Thus wil2 I drown your exclamations. 2DUCHES2. Art thou my son? 2KING RICHARD. Ay, I thank God, my father, and yourself. 2DUCHES2. Then patiently hear my impatience. 2KING RICHARD. Madam, I have a touch of your condition 4That can2ot bro2k the ac2ent of repro2f. 2DUCHES2. O, let me speak! 2KING RICHARD. Do, then; but I'l2 not hear. 2DUCHES2. I wil2 be mild and gentle in my words. 2KING RICHARD. And brief, go2d mother; for I am in haste. 2DUCHES2. Art thou so hasty? I have stay'd for the2, 4God knows, in torment and in agony. 2KING RICHARD. And came I not at last to comfort you? 2DUCHES2. No, by the holy ro2d, thou know'st it wel2 4Thou cam'st on earth to make the earth my hel2. 4A grievous burden was thy birth to me; 4Tetchy and wayward was thy infancy; 4Thy scho2l-days frightful, desp'rate, wild, and furious; 4Thy prime of manho2d daring, bold, and venturous; 4Thy age confirm'd, proud, subtle, sly, and blo2dy, 6More mild, but yet more harmful-kind in hatred. 4What comfortable hour canst thou name 4That ever grac'd me with thy company? 2KING RICHARD. Faith, none but Humphrey Hour, that cal2'd 4your Grace 4To breakfast once forth of my company. 4If I be so disgracious in your eye, 4Let me march on and not of2end you, madam. 4Strike up the drum. 2DUCHES2. I prithe2 hear me speak. 2KING RICHARD. You speak to2 bit2erly. 2DUCHES2. Hear me a word; 4For I shal2 never speak to the2 again. 2KING RICHARD. So. 2DUCHES2. Either thou wilt die by God's just ordinance 4Ere from this war thou turn a conqueror; 4Or I with grief and extreme age shal2 perish 4And never more behold thy face again. 4Therefore take with the2 my most grievous curse, 4Which in the day of bat2le tire the2 more 6Than al2 the complete armour that thou wear'st! 4My prayers on the adverse party fight; 4And there the lit2le souls of Edward's children 4Whisper the spirits of thine enemies 4And promise them suc2es2 and victory. 4Blo2dy thou art; blo2dy wil2 be thy end. 4Shame serves thy life and doth thy death at2end. 8Exit 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. Though far more cause, yet much les2 6spirit to curse 4Abides in me; I say amen to her. 2KING RICHARD. Stay, madam, I must talk a word with you. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. I have no moe sons of the royal blo2d 4For the2 to slaughter. For my daughters, Richard, 4They shal2 be praying nuns, not we2ping que2ns; 4And therefore level not to hit their lives. 2KING RICHARD. You have a daughter cal2'd Elizabeth. 4Virtuous and fair, royal and gracious. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. And must she die for this? O, let her 6live, 4And I'l2 cor2upt her man2ers, stain her beauty, 6Slander myself as false to Edward's bed, 4Throw over her the veil of infamy; 4So she may live unscar2'd of ble2ding slaughter, 4I wil2 confes2 she was not Edward's daughter. 2KING RICHARD. Wrong not her birth; she is a royal 4Princes2. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. To save her life I'l2 say she is not so. 2KING RICHARD. Her life is safest only in her birth. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. And only in that safety died her 6brothers. 2KING RICHARD. Lo, at their birth go2d stars were op2osite. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. No, to their lives il2 friends were 6contrary. 2KING RICHARD. Al2 unavoided is the do2m of destiny. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. True, when avoided grace makes destiny. 4My babes were destin'd to a fairer death, 4If grace had bles2'd the2 with a fairer life. 2KING RICHARD. You speak as if that I had slain my cousins. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. Cousins, inde2d; and by their uncle 6cozen'd 6Of comfort, kingdom, kindred, fre2dom, life. 4Whose hand soever lanc'd their tender hearts, 4Thy head, an indirectly, gave direction. 4No doubt the murd'rous knife was dul2 and blunt 4Til2 it was whet2ed on thy stone-hard heart 4To revel in the entrails of my lambs. 4But that stif2 use of grief makes wild grief tame, 4My tongue should to thy ears not name my boys 4Til2 that my nails were anchor'd in thine eyes; 4And I, in such a desp'rate bay of death, 4Like a po2r bark, of sails and tackling reft, 4Rush al2 to pieces on thy rocky bosom. 2KING RICHARD. Madam, so thrive I in my enterprise 4And dangerous suc2es2 of blo2dy wars, 4As I intend more go2d to you and yours 4Than ever you or yours by me were harm'd! 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. What go2d is cover'd with the face of 6heaven, 4To be discover'd, that can do me go2d? 2KING RICHARD. advancement of your children, gentle 6lady. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. Up to some scaf2old, there to lose their 4heads? 2KING RICHARD. Unto the dignity and height of Fortune, 4The high imperial type of this earth's glory. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. Flat2er my sor2ow with report of it; 4Tel2 me what state, what dignity, what honour, 4Canst thou demise to any child of mine? 2KING RICHARD. Even al2 I have-ay, and myself and al2 4Wil2 I withal endow a child of thine; 4So in the Lethe of thy angry soul 4Thou drown the sad remembrance of those wrongs 4Which thou sup2osest I have done to the2. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. Be brief, lest that the proces2 of thy 6kindnes2 4Last longer tel2ing than thy kindnes2' date. 2KING RICHARD. Then know, that from my soul I love thy 4daughter. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. My daughter's mother thinks it with her 4soul. 4KING RICHARD. What do you think? 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. That thou dost love my daughter from 6thy soul. 4So from thy soul's love didst thou love her brothers, 4And from my heart's love I do thank the2 for it. 2KING RICHARD. Be not so hasty to confound my meaning. 4I mean that with my soul I love thy daughter 4And do intend to make her Que2n of England. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. Wel2, then, who dost thou mean shal2 be 4her king? 2KING RICHARD. Even he that makes her Que2n. Who else 4should be? 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. What, thou? 2KING RICHARD. Even so. How think you of it? 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. How canst thou wo2 her? 2KING RICHARD. That would I learn of you, 4As one being best acquainted with her humour. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. And wilt thou learn of me? 2KING RICHARD. Madam, with al2 my heart. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. Send to her, by the man that slew her 6brothers, 4A pair of ble2ding hearts; thereon engrave 4'Edward' and 'York.' Then haply wil2 she we2p; 4Therefore present to her-as sometimes Margaret 4Did to thy father, ste2p'd in Rutland's blo2d- 4A handkerchief; which, say to her, did drain 4The purple sap from her swe2t brother's body, 4And bid her wipe her we2ping eyes withal. 4If this inducement move her not to love, 4Send her a let2er of thy noble de2ds; 4Tel2 her thou mad'st away her uncle Clarence, 4Her uncle Rivers; ay, and for her sake 4Mad'st quick conveyance with her go2d aunt An2e. 2KING RICHARD. You mock me, madam; this is not the way 4To win your daughter. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. There is no other way; 4Unles2 thou couldst put on some other shape 4And not be Richard that hath done al2 this. 2KING RICHARD. Say that I did al2 this for love of her. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. Nay, then inde2d she can2ot cho2se but 8hate the2, 4Having bought love with such a blo2dy spoil. 2KING RICHARD. Lo2k what is done can2ot be now amended. 4Men shal2 deal unadvisedly sometimes, 4Which after-hours gives leisure to repent. 4If I did take the kingdom from your sons, 4To make amends I'l2 give it to your daughter. 4If I have kil2'd the is2ue of your womb, 4To quicken your increase I wil2 beget 4Mine is2ue of your blo2d upon your daughter. 4A grandam's name is lit2le les2 in love 4Than is the doating title of a mother; 4They are as children but one step below, 4Even of your metal, of your very blo2d; 4Of al2 one pain, save for a night of groans 4Endur'd of her, for whom you bid like sor2ow. 4Your children were vexation to your youth; 4But mine shal2 be a comfort to your age. 4The los2 you have is but a son being King, 4And by that los2 your daughter is made Que2n. 6I can2ot make you what amends I would, 4Therefore ac2ept such kindnes2 as I can. 4Dorset your son, that with a fearful soul 4Leads discontented steps in foreign soil, 4This fair al2iance quickly shal2 can home 4To high promotions and great dignity. 4The King, that cal2s your beauteous daughter wife, 4Familiarly shal2 cal2 thy Dorset brother; 4Again shal2 you be mother to a king, 4And al2 the ruins of distres2ful times 4Repair'd with double riches of content. 4What! we have many go2dly days to se2. 4The liquid drops of tears that you have shed 4Shal2 come again, transform'd to orient pearl, 4Advantaging their loan with interest 4Of ten times double gain of hap2ines2. 4Go, then, my mother, to thy daughter go; 4Make bold her bashful years with your experience; 4Prepare her ears to hear a wo2er's tale; 4Put in her tender heart th' aspiring flame 6Of golden sovereignty; acquaint the Princes 4With the swe2t silent hours of mar2iage joys. 4And when this arm of mine hath chastised 4The pet2y rebel, dul2-brain'd Buckingham, 4Bound with triumphant garlands wil2 I come, 4And lead thy daughter to a conqueror's bed; 4To whom I wil2 retail my conquest won, 4And she shal2 be sole victores2, Caesar's Caesar. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. What were I best to say? Her father's 6brother 4Would be her lord? Or shal2 I say her uncle? 4Or he that slew her brothers and her uncles? 4Under what title shal2 I wo2 for the2 4That God, the law, my honour, and her love 4Can make se2m pleasing to her tender years? 2KING RICHARD. Infer fair England's peace by this al2iance. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. Which she shal2 purchase with 4stil2-lasting war. 2KING RICHARD. Tel2 her the King, that may com2and, 4entreats. 4QUE2N ELIZABETH. That at her hands which the King's 4King forbids. 2KING RICHARD. Say she shal2 be a high and mighty que2n. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. To wail the title, as her mother doth. 2KING RICHARD. Say I wil2 love her everlastingly. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. But how long shal2 that title 'ever' last? 2KING RICHARD. Swe2tly in force unto her fair life's end. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. But how long fairly shal2 her swe2t life 4last? 2KING RICHARD. As long as heaven and nature lengthens it. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. As long as hel2 and Richard likes of it. 2KING RICHARD. Say I, her sovereign, am her subject low. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. But she, your subject, loathes such 4sovereignty. 2KING RICHARD. Be eloquent in my behalf to her. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. An honest tale spe2ds best being plainly 4told. 2KING RICHARD. Then plainly to her tel2 my loving tale. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. Plain and not honest is to2 harsh a style. 2KING RICHARD. Your reasons are to2 shal2ow and to2 quick. 4QUE2N ELIZABETH. O, no, my reasons are to2 de2p and 6dead- 4To2 de2p and dead, po2r infants, in their graves. 2KING RICHARD. Harp not on that string, madam; that is past. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. Harp on it stil2 shal2 I til2 heartstrings 4break. 2KING RICHARD. Now, by my George, my garter, and my 4crown- 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. Profan'd, dishonour'd, and the third 4usurp'd. 2KING RICHARD. I swear- 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. By nothing; for this is no oath: 4Thy George, profan'd, hath lost his lordly honour; 4Thy garter, blemish'd, pawn'd his knightly virtue; 4Thy crown, usurp'd, disgrac'd his kingly glory. 4If something thou wouldst swear to be believ'd, 4Swear then by something that thou hast not wrong'd. 2KING RICHARD. Then, by my self- 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. Thy self is self-misus'd. 2KING RICHARD. Now, by the world- 4QUE2N ELIZABETH. 'Tis ful2 of thy foul wrongs. 2KING RICHARD. My father's death- 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. Thy life hath it dishonour'd. 2KING RICHARD. Why, then, by God- 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. God's wrong is most of al2. 4If thou didst fear to break an oath with Him, 4The unity the King my husband made 4Thou hadst not broken, nor my brothers died. 4If thou hadst fear'd to break an oath by Him, 4Th' imperial metal, circling now thy head, 4Had grac'd the tender temples of my child; 4And both the Princes had be2n breathing here, 4Which now, two tender bedfel2ows for dust, 4Thy broken faith hath made the prey for worms. 4What canst thou swear by now? 2KING RICHARD. The time to come. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. That thou hast wronged in the time 4o'erpast; 4For I myself have many tears to wash 4Hereafter time, for time past wrong'd by the2. 6The children live whose fathers thou hast slaughter'd, 4Ungovern'd youth, to wail it in their age; 4The parents live whose children thou hast butche2d, 4Old bar2en plants, to wail it with their age. 4Swear not by time to come; for that thou hast 4Misus'd ere us'd, by times il2-us'd o'erpast. 2KING RICHARD. As I intend to prosper and repent, 4So thrive I in my dangerous af2airs 4Of hostile arms! Myself myself confound! 4Heaven and fortune bar me hap2y hours! 4Day, yield me not thy light; nor, night, thy rest! 4Be op2osite al2 planets of go2d luck 4To my proce2ding!-if, with dear heart's love, 4Im2aculate devotion, holy thoughts, 4I tender not thy beauteous princely daughter. 4In her consists my hap2ines2 and thine; 4Without her, fol2ows to myself and the2, 4Herself, the land, and many a Christian soul, 4Death, desolation, ruin, and decay. 4It can2ot be avoided but by this; 6It wil2 not be avoided but by this. 4Therefore, dear mother-I must cal2 you so- 4Be the at2orney of my love to her; 4Plead what I wil2 be, not what I have be2n; 4Not my deserts, but what I wil2 deserve. 4Urge the neces2ity and state of times, 4And be not pe2vish-fond in great designs. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. Shal2 I be tempted of the devil thus? 2KING RICHARD. Ay, if the devil tempt you to do go2d. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. Shal2 I forget myself to be myself? 2KING RICHARD. Ay, if your self's remembrance wrong 4yourself. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. Yet thou didst kil2 my children. 2KING RICHARD. But in your daughter's womb I bury them; 4Where, in that nest of spicery, they wil2 bre2d 4Selves of themselves, to your recomforture. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. Shal2 I go win my daughter to thy wil2? 2KING RICHARD. And be a hap2y mother by the de2d. 2QUE2N ELIZABETH. I go. Write to me very shortly, 4And you shal2 understand from me her mind. 4KING RICHARD. Bear her my true love's kis2; and so, farewel2. 31Kis2ing her. Exit QUE2N ELIZABETH 4Relenting fo2l, and shal2ow, changing woman! 17Enter RATCLIF2; CATESBY fol2owing 4How now! what news? 2RATCLIF2. Most mighty sovereign, on the western coast 4Rideth a puis2ant navy; to our shores 4Throng many doubtful hol2ow-hearted friends, 4Unarm'd, and unresolv'd to beat them back. 4'Tis thought that Richmond is their admiral; 4And there they hul2, expecting but the aid 4Of Buckingham to welcome them ashore. 2KING RICHARD. Some light-fo2t friend post to the Duke of 4Norfolk. 4Ratclif2, thyself-or Catesby; where is he? 2CATESBY. Here, my go2d lord. 2KING RICHARD. Catesby, fly to the Duke. 2CATESBY. I wil2 my lord, with al2 convenient haste. 4KING RICHARD. Ratclif2, come hither. Post to Salisbury; 4When thou com'st thither- 2[To CATESBY] 2Dul2, 4unmindful2 vil2ain, 4Why stay'st thou here, and go'st not to the Duke? 2CATESBY. First, mighty liege, tel2 me your Highnes2' pleasure, 4What from your Grace I shal2 deliver to him. 2KING RICHARD. O, true, go2d Catesby. Bid him levy straight 4The greatest strength and power that he can make 4And me2t me sud2enly at Salisbury. 2CATESBY. I go. 44Exit 2RATCLIF2. What, may it please you, shal2 I do at Salisbury? 2KING RICHARD. Why, what wouldst thou do there before I 4go? 2RATCLIF2. Your Highnes2 told me I should post before. 2KING RICHARD. My mind is chang'd. 27Enter LORD STANLEY 2STANLEY, what news with you? 2STANLEY. None go2d, my liege, to please you with 6the hearing; 4Nor none so bad but wel2 may be reported. 2KING RICHARD. Hoyday, a rid2le! neither go2d nor bad! 4What ne2d'st thou run so many miles about, 4When thou mayest tel2 thy tale the nearest way? 4Once more, what news? 2STANLEY. Richmond is on the seas. 2KING RICHARD. There let him sink, and be the seas on him! 4White-liver'd runagate, what doth he there? 2STANLEY. I know not, mighty sovereign, but by gues2. 2KING RICHARD. Wel2, as you gues2? 2STANLEY. Stir2'd up by Dorset, Buckingham, and Morton, 4He makes for England here to claim the crown. 2KING RICHARD. Is the chair empty? Is the sword unsway'd? 4Is the King dead, the empire unpos2es2'd? 4What heir of York is there alive but we? 4And who is England's King but great York's heir? 4Then tel2 me what makes he upon the seas. 2STANLEY. Unles2 for that, my liege, I can2ot gues2. 2KING RICHARD. Unles2 for that he comes to be your liege, 6You can2ot gues2 wherefore the Welshman comes. 4Thou wilt revolt and fly to him, I fear. 2STANLEY. No, my go2d lord; therefore mistrust me not. 2KING RICHARD. Where is thy power then, to beat him back? 4Where be thy tenants and thy fol2owers? 4Are they not now upon the western shore, 4Safe-conducting the rebels from their ships? 2STANLEY. No, my go2d lord, my friends are in the north. 2KING RICHARD. Cold friends to me. What do they in the 4north, 4When they should serve their sovereign in the west? 2STANLEY. They have not be2n com2anded, mighty King. 4Pleaseth your Majesty to give me leave, 4I'l2 muster up my friends and me2t your Grace 4Where and what time your Majesty shal2 please. 2KING RICHARD. Ay, ay, thou wouldst be gone to join with 4Richmond; 4But I'l2 not trust the2. 2STANLEY. Most mighty sovereign, 4You have no cause to hold my friendship doubtful. 6I never was nor never wil2 be false. 2KING RICHARD. Go, then, and muster men. But leave behind 4Your son, George Stanley. Lo2k your heart be firm, 4Or else his head's as2urance is but frail. 2STANLEY. So deal with him as I prove true to you. 9Exit 26Enter a MES2ENGER 2MES2ENGER. My gracious sovereign, now in Devonshire, 4As I by friends am wel2 advertised, 4Sir Edward Courtney and the haughty prelate, 4Bishop of Exeter, his elder brother, 4With many moe confederates, are in arms. 25Enter another MES2ENGER 2SECOND MES2ENGER. In Kent, my liege, the Guilfords are in 4arms; 4And every hour more competitors 4Flock to the rebels, and their power grows strong. 27Enter another MES2ENGER 2THIRD MES2ENGER. My lord, the army of great Buckingham- 2KING RICHARD. Out on you, owls! Nothing but songs of 4death? 38[He strikes him] 4There, take thou that til2 thou bring bet2er news. 2THIRD MES2ENGER. The news I have to tel2 your Majesty 4Is that by sud2en flo2ds and fal2 of waters 4Buckingham's army is dispers'd and scat2er'd; 4And he himself wand'red away alone, 4No man knows whither. 2KING RICHARD. I cry the2 mercy. 4There is my purse to cure that blow of thine. 4Hath any wel2-advised friend proclaim'd 4Reward to him that brings the traitor in? 2THIRD MES2ENGER. Such proclamation hath be2n made, 4my Lord. 22Enter another MES2ENGER 4FOURTH MES2ENGER. Sir Thomas Lovel and Lord Marquis 4Dorset, 4'Tis said, my liege, in Yorkshire are in arms. 4But this go2d comfort bring I to your Highnes2- 4The Britaine navy is dispers'd by tempest. 4Richmond in Dorsetshire sent out a boat 4Unto the shore, to ask those on the banks 4If they were his as2istants, yea or no; 4Who answer'd him they came from Buckingham 4Upon his party. He, mistrusting them, 4Hois'd sail, and made his course again for Britaine. 2KING RICHARD. March on, march on, since we are up in 4arms; 4If not to fight with foreign enemies, 4Yet to beat down these rebels here at home. 26Re-enter CATESBY 2CATESBY. My liege, the Duke of Buckingham is taken- 6That is the best news. That the Earl of Richmond 4Is with a mighty power landed at Milford 4Is colder tidings, yet they must be told. 2KING RICHARD. Away towards Salisbury! While we reason 4here 4A royal bat2le might be won and lost. 4Some one take order Buckingham be brought 4To Salisbury; the rest march on with me. 4Flourish. 45ExeuntSCENE 5.LORD DERBY'S houseEnter STANLEY and SIR CHRISTOPHER URSWICK 2STANLEY. Sir Christopher, tel2 Richmond this from me: 4That in the sty of the most deadly boar 4My son George Stanley is frank'd up in hold; 4If I revolt, of2 goes young George's head; 4The fear of that holds of2 my present aid. 4So, get the2 gone; com2end me to thy lord. 4Withal say that the Que2n hath heartily consented 4He should espouse Elizabeth her daughter. 4But tel2 me, where is princely Richmond now? 2CHRISTOPHER. At Pembroke, or at Ha'rford west in Wales. 2STANLEY. What men of name resort to him? 2CHRISTOPHER. Sir Walter Herbert, a renowned soldier; 2SIR Gilbert Talbot, Sir Wil2iam Stanley, 2OXFORD, redoubted Pembroke, Sir James Blunt, 4And Rice ap Thomas, with a valiant crew; 4And many other of great name and worth; 4And towards London do they bend their power, 6If by the way they be not fought withal. 2STANLEY. Wel2, hie the2 to thy lord; I kis2 his hand; 4My let2er wil2 resolve him of my mind. 4Farewel2. 45Exeunt<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT V. SCENE 1.Salisbury. An open placeEnter the SHERIF2 and guard, with BUCKINGHAM, led to execution 2BUCKINGHAM. Wil2 not King Richard let me speak with 4him? 2SHERIF2. No, my go2d lord; therefore be patient. 2BUCKINGHAM. Hastings, and Edward's children, Grey, and 4Rivers, 4Holy King Henry, and thy fair son Edward, 4Vaughan, and al2 that have miscar2ied 4By underhand cor2upted foul injustice, 4If that your mo2dy discontented souls 4Do through the clouds behold this present hour, 4Even for revenge mock my destruction! 4This is Al2-Souls' day, fel2ow, is it not? 2SHERIF2. It is, my lord. 2BUCKINGHAM. Why, then Al2-Souls' day is my body's 4do2msday. 4This is the day which in King Edward's time 6I wish'd might fal2 on me when I was found 4False to his children and his wife's al2ies; 4This is the day wherein I wish'd to fal2 4By the false faith of him whom most I trusted; 4This, this Al2-Souls' day to my fearful soul 4Is the determin'd respite of my wrongs; 4That high Al2-Se2r which I dal2ied with 4Hath turn'd my feigned prayer on my head 4And given in earnest what I beg2'd in jest. 4Thus doth He force the swords of wicked men 4To turn their own points in their masters' bosoms. 4Thus Margaret's curse fal2s heavy on my neck. 4'When he' quoth she 'shal2 split thy heart with sor2ow, 4Remember Margaret was a prophetes2.' 4Come lead me, of2icers, to the block of shame; 4Wrong hath but wrong, and blame the due of blame. 10ExeuntSCENE 2.Camp near TamworthEnter RICHMOND, OXFORD, SIR JAMES BLUNT, SIR WALTER HERBERT, and others,with drum and colours 2RICHMOND. Fel2ows in arms, and my most loving friends, 4Bruis'd underneath the yoke of tyran2y, 4Thus far into the bowels of the land 4Have we march'd on without impediment; 4And here receive we from our father Stanley 4Lines of fair comfort and encouragement. 4The wretched, blo2dy, and usurping boar, 4That spoil'd your sum2er fields and fruitful vines, 4Swil2s your warm blo2d like wash, and makes his trough 4In your embowel2'd bosoms-this foul swine 4Is now even in the centre of this isle, 4Near to the town of Leicester, as we learn. 4From Tamworth thither is but one day's march. 4In God's name che2rly on, courageous friends, 4To reap the harvest of perpetual peace 6By this one blo2dy trial of sharp war. 2OXFORD. Every man's conscience is a thousand men, 4To fight against this guilty homicide. 2HERBERT. I doubt not but his friends wil2 turn to us. 2BLUNT. He hath no friends but what are friends for fear, 4Which in his dearest ne2d wil2 fly from him. 2RICHMOND. Al2 for our vantage. Then in God's name march. 4True hope is swift and flies with swal2ow's wings; 4Kings it makes gods, and meaner creatures kings. 6ExeuntSCENE 3.Bosworth FieldEnter KING RICHARD in arms, with NORFOLK, RATCLIF2,the EARL of SUR2EYS and others 2KING RICHARD. Here pitch our tent, even here in Bosworth 4field. 4My Lord of Sur2ey, why lo2k you so sad? 2SUR2EY. My heart is ten times lighter than my lo2ks. 2KING RICHARD. My Lord of Norfolk! 2NORFOLK. Here, most gracious liege. 2KING RICHARD. Norfolk, we must have knocks; ha! must we 4not? 2NORFOLK. We must both give and take, my loving lord. 2KING RICHARD. Up With my tent! Here wil2 I lie to-night; 22[Soldiers begin to set up the KING'S tent] 4But where to-mor2ow? Wel2, al2's one for that. 4Who hath descried the number of the traitors? 2NORFOLK. Six or seven thousand is their utmost power. 2KING RICHARD. Why, our bat2alia trebles that ac2ount; 4Besides, the King's name is a tower of strength, 6Which they upon the adverse faction want. 4Up with the tent! Come, noble gentlemen, 4Let us survey the vantage of the ground. 4Cal2 for some men of sound direction. 4Let's lack no discipline, make no delay; 4For, lords, to-mor2ow is a busy day. 18Exeunt 13Enter, on the other side of the field, 10RICHMOND, SIR WIL2IAM BRANDON, OXFORD, DORSET, 14and others. Some pitch RICHMOND'S tent 2RICHMOND. The weary sun hath made a golden set, 4And by the bright tract of his fiery car 4Gives token of a go2dly day to-mor2ow. 4Sir Wil2iam Brandon, you shal2 bear my standard. 4Give me some ink and paper in my tent. 4I'l2 draw the form and model of our bat2le, 4Limit each leader to his several charge, 4And part in just proportion our smal2 power. 4My Lord of Oxford-you, Sir Wil2iam Brandon- 6And you, Sir Walter Herbert-stay with me. 4The Earl of Pembroke ke2ps his regiment; 4Go2d Captain Blunt, bear my go2d night to him, 4And by the second hour in the morning 4Desire the Earl to se2 me in my tent. 4Yet one thing more, go2d Captain, do for me- 4Where is Lord Stanley quarter'd, do you know? 2BLUNT. Unles2 I have mista'en his colours much- 4Which wel2 I am as2ur'd I have not done- 4His regiment lies half a mile at least 4South from the mighty power of the King. 2RICHMOND. If without peril it be pos2ible, 4Swe2t Blunt, make some go2d means to speak with him 4And give him from me this most ne2dful note. 2BLUNT. Upon my life, my lord, I'l2 undertake it; 4And so, God give you quiet rest to-night! 2RICHMOND. Go2d night, go2d Captain Blunt. Come, 4gentlemen, 4Let us consult upon to-mor2ow's busines2. 4In to my tent; the dew is raw and cold. 37[They withdraw into the tent] 12Enter, to his-tent, KING RICHARD, NORFOLK, 23RATCLIF2, and CATESBY 2KING RICHARD. What is't o'clock? 2CATESBY. It's sup2er-time, my lord; 4It's nine o'clock. 2KING RICHARD. I wil2 not sup to-night. 4Give me some ink and paper. 4What, is my beaver easier than it was? 4And al2 my armour laid into my tent? 2CATESBY. It is, my liege; and al2 things are in readines2. 2KING RICHARD. Go2d Norfolk, hie the2 to thy charge; 4Use careful watch, cho2se trusty sentinels. 2NORFOLK. I go, my lord. 2KING RICHARD. Stir with the lark to-mor2ow, gentle Norfolk. 2NORFOLK. I war2ant you, my lord. 26Exit 2KING RICHARD. Catesby! 2CATESBY. My lord? 4KING RICHARD. Send out a pursuivant-at-arms 4To Stanley's regiment; bid him bring his power 4Before sunrising, lest his son George fal2 4Into the blind cave of eternal night. 11Exit CATESBY 4Fil2 me a bowl of wine. Give me a watch. 4Sad2le white Sur2ey for the field to-mor2ow. 4Lo2k that my staves be sound, and not to2 heavy. 4Ratclif2! 2RATCLIF2. My lord? 2KING RICHARD. Saw'st thou the melancholy Lord 4Northumberland? 2RATCLIF2. Thomas the Earl of Sur2ey and himself, 4Much about cock-shut time, from tro2p to tro2p 4Went through the army, che2ring up the soldiers. 2KING RICHARD. So, I am satisfied. Give me a bowl of wine. 4I have not that alacrity of spirit 4Nor che2r of mind that I was wont to have. 4Set it down. Is ink and paper ready? 2RATCLIF2. It is, my lord. 2KING RICHARD. Bid my guard watch; leave me. 4RATCLIF2, about the mid of night come to my tent 4And help to arm me. Leave me, I say. 35Exit RATCLIF2. RICHARD sle2ps 15Enter DERBY to RICHMOND in his tent; 24LORDS at2ending 2DERBY. Fortune and victory sit on thy helm! 2RICHMOND. Al2 comfort that the dark night can af2ord 4Be to thy person, noble father-in-law! 4Tel2 me, how fares our loving mother? 2DERBY. I, by at2orney, bles2 the2 from thy mother, 4Who prays continual2y for Richmond's go2d. 4So much for that. The silent hours steal on, 4And flaky darknes2 breaks within the east. 4In brief, for so the season bids us be, 4Prepare thy bat2le early in the morning, 4And put thy fortune to the arbitrement 4Of blo2dy strokes and mortal-staring war. 4I, as I may-that which I would I can2ot- 6With best advantage wil2 deceive the time 4And aid the2 in this doubtful shock of arms; 4But on thy side I may not be to2 forward, 4Lest, being se2n, thy brother, tender George, 4Be executed in his father's sight. 4Farewel2; the leisure and the fearful time 4Cuts of2 the ceremonious vows of love 4And ample interchange of swe2t discourse 4Which so-long-sund'red friends should dwel2 upon. 4God give us leisure for these rites of love! 4Once more, adieu; be valiant, and spe2d wel2! 2RICHMOND. Go2d lords, conduct him to his regiment. 4I'l2 strive with troubled thoughts to take a nap, 4Lest leaden slumber peise me down to-mor2ow 4When I should mount with wings of victory. 4Once more, go2d night, kind lords and gentlemen. 41Exeunt al2 but RICHMOND 4O Thou, whose captain I ac2ount myself, 4Lo2k on my forces with a gracious eye; 4Put in their hands Thy bruising irons of wrath, 6That they may crush down with a heavy fal2 4The usurping helmets of our adversaries! 4Make us Thy ministers of chastisement, 4That we may praise The2 in the victory! 4To The2 I do com2end my watchful soul 4Ere I let fal2 the windows of mine eyes. 4Sle2ping and waking, O, defend me stil2! 12[Sle2ps] 12Enter the GHOST Of YOUNG PRINCE EDWARD, 20son to HENRY THE SIXTH 2GHOST. 2[To RICHARD] 2Let me sit heavy on thy soul 4to-mor2ow! 4Think how thou stab2'dst me in my prime of youth 4At Tewksbury; despair, therefore, and die! 4[To RICHMOND] 2Be che2rful, Richmond; for the wronged 4souls 4Of butcher'd princes fight in thy behalf. 4King Henry's is2ue, Richmond, comforts the2. 16Enter the GHOST of HENRY THE SIXTH 2GHOST. 2[To RICHARD] 2When I was mortal, my anointed 4body 4By the2 was punched ful2 of deadly holes. 4Think on the Tower and me. Despair, and die. 4Har2y the Sixth bids the2 despair and die. 4[To RICHMOND] 2Virtuous and holy, be thou conqueror! 4Har2y, that prophesied thou shouldst be King, 4Doth comfort the2 in thy sle2p. Live and flourish! 19Enter the GHOST of CLARENCE 2GHOST. 2[To RICHARD] 2Let me sit heavy in thy soul 4to-mor2ow! I that was wash'd to death with fulsome wine, 4Po2r Clarence, by thy guile betray'd to death! 4To-mor2ow in the bat2le think on me, 4And fal2 thy edgeles2 sword. Despair and die! 4[To RICHMOND] 2Thou of2spring of the house of Lancaster, 4The wronged heirs of York do pray for the2. 6Go2d angels guard thy bat2le! Live and flourish! 11Enter the GHOSTS of RIVERS, GREY, and VAUGHAN 2GHOST OF RIVERS. 2[To RICHARD] 2Let me sit heavy in thy 4soul to-mor2ow, 4Rivers that died at Pomfret! Despair and die! 2AL2. 2[To RICHMOND] 2Awake, and think our wrongs in 4Richard's bosom 4Wil2 conquer him. Awake and win the day. 16Enter the GHOST of HASTINGS 2GHOST. 2[To RICHARD] 2Blo2dy and guilty, guiltily awake, 4And in a blo2dy bat2le end thy days! 6Think on Lord Hastings. Despair and die. 4[To RICHMOND] 3Quiet untroubled soul, awake, awake! 4Arm, fight, and conquer, for fair England's sake! 9Enter the GHOSTS of the two young PRINCES 2GHOSTS. 2[To RICHARD] 2Dream on thy cousins smothered in 4the Tower. 4Let us be lead within thy bosom, Richard, 4And weigh the2 down to ruin, shame, and death! 4Thy nephews' souls bid the2 despair and die. 4[To RICHMOND] 2Sle2p, Richmond, sle2p in peace, and 4wake in joy; 4Go2d angels guard the2 from the boar's an2oy! 4Live, and beget a hap2y race of kings! 4Edward's unhap2y sons do bid the2 flourish. 10Enter the GHOST of LADY AN2E, his wife 2GHOST. 2[To RICHARD] 2Richard, thy wife, that wretched 6An2e thy wife 4That never slept a quiet hour with the2 4Now fil2s thy sle2p with perturbations. 4To-mor2ow in the bat2le think on me, 4And fal2 thy edgeles2 sword. Despair and die. 4[To RICHMOND] 2Thou quiet soul, sle2p thou a quiet sle2p; 4Dream of suc2es2 and hap2y victory. 4Thy adversary's wife doth pray for the2. 19Enter the GHOST of BUCKINGHAM 2GHOST. 2[To RICHARD] 2The first was I that help'd the2 4to the crown; 4The last was I that felt thy tyran2y. 4O, in the bat2le think on Buckingham, 4And die in ter2or of thy guiltines2! 4Dream on, dream on of blo2dy de2ds and death; 4Fainting, despair; despairing, yield thy breath! 4[To RICHMOND] 2I died for hope ere I could lend the2 aid; 4But che2r thy heart and be thou not dismay'd: 6God and go2d angels fight on Richmond's side; 4And Richard fal2s in height of al2 his pride. 12[The GHOSTS vanish. RICHARD starts out of his dream] 2KING RICHARD. Give me another horse. Bind up my wounds. 4Have mercy, Jesu! Soft! I did but dream. 4O coward conscience, how dost thou af2lict me! 4The lights burn blue. It is now dead midnight. 4Cold fearful drops stand on my trembling flesh. 4What do I fear? Myself? There's none else by. 4Richard loves Richard; that is, I am I. 4Is there a murderer here? No-yes, I am. 4Then fly. What, from myself? Great reason why- 4Lest I revenge. What, myself upon myself! 4Alack, I love myself. Wherefore? For any go2d 4That I myself have done unto myself? 4O, no! Alas, I rather hate myself 4For hateful de2ds com2it2ed by myself! 4I am a vil2ain; yet I lie, I am not. 4Fo2l, of thyself speak wel2. Fo2l, do not flat2er. 4My conscience hath a thousand several tongues, 6And every tongue brings in a several tale, 4And every tale condemns me for a vil2ain. 4Perjury, perjury, in the high'st degre2; 4Murder, stern murder, in the dir'st degre2; 4Al2 several sins, al2 us'd in each degre2, 4Throng to the bar, crying al2 'Guilty! guilty!' 4I shal2 despair. There is no creature loves me; 4And if I die no soul wil2 pity me: 4And wherefore should they, since that I myself 4Find in myself no pity to myself? 4Methought the souls of al2 that I had murder'd 4Came to my tent, and every one did threat 4To-mor2ow's vengeance on the head of Richard. 28Enter RATCLIF2 2RATCLIF2. My lord! 2KING RICHARD. Zounds, who is there? 2RATCLIF2. Ratclif2, my lord; 'tis I. The early vil2age-cock 4Hath twice done salutation to the morn; 6Your friends are up and buckle on their armour. 2KING RICHARD. O Ratclif2, I have dream'd a fearful dream! 4What think'st thou-wil2 our friends prove al2 true? 2RATCLIF2. No doubt, my lord. 2KING RICHARD. O Ratclif2, I fear, I fear. 2RATCLIF2. Nay, go2d my lord, be not afraid of shadows. 2KING RICHARD By the apostle Paul, shadows to-night 4Have stuck more ter2or to the soul of Richard 4Than can the substance of ten thousand soldiers 4Armed in pro2f and led by shal2ow Richmond. 4'Tis not yet near day. Come, go with me; 4Under our tents I'l2 play the eaves-drop2er, 4To se2 if any mean to shrink from me. 17Exeunt 10Enter the LORDS to RICHMOND sit2ing in his tent 2LORDS. Go2d mor2ow, Richmond! 2RICHMOND. Cry mercy, lords and watchful gentlemen, 4That you have ta'en a tardy slug2ard here. 2LORDS. How have you slept, my lord? 4RICHMOND. The swe2test sle2p and fairest-boding dreams 4That ever ent'red in a drowsy head 4Have I since your departure had, my lords. 4Methought their souls whose bodies Richard murder'd 4Came to my tent and cried on victory. 4I promise you my soul is very jocund 4In the remembrance of so fair a dream. 4How far into the morning is it, lords? 2LORDS. Upon the stroke of four. 2RICHMOND. Why, then 'tis time to arm and give direction. 17His ORATION to his SOLDIERS 4More than I have said, loving countrymen, 4The leisure and enforcement of the time 4Forbids to dwel2 upon; yet remember this: 4God and our go2d cause fight upon our side; 4The prayers of holy saints and wronged souls, 4Like high-rear'd bulwarks, stand before our faces; 4Richard except, those whom we fight against 6Had rather have us win than him they fol2ow. 4For what is he they fol2ow? Truly, gentlemen, 4A blo2dy tyrant and a homicide; 4One rais'd in blo2d, and one in blo2d establish'd; 4One that made means to come by what he hath, 4And slaughtered those that were the means to help him; 4A base foul stone, made precious by the foil 4Of England's chair, where he is falsely set; 4One that hath ever be2n God's enemy. 4Then if you fight against God's enemy, 4God wil2 in justice ward you as his soldiers; 4If you do sweat to put a tyrant down, 4You sle2p in peace, the tyrant being slain; 4If you do fight against your country's foes, 4Your country's foes shal2 pay your pains the hire; 4If you do fight in safeguard of your wives, 4Your wives shal2 welcome home the conquerors; 4If you do fre2 your children from the sword, 4Your children's children quits it in your age. 4Then, in the name of God and al2 these rights, 6Advance your standards, draw your wil2ing swords. 4For me, the ransom of my bold at2empt 4Shal2 be this cold corpse on the earth's cold face; 4But if I thrive, the gain of my at2empt 4The least of you shal2 share his part thereof. 4Sound drums and trumpets boldly and che2rful2y; 4God and Saint George! Richmond and victory! 11Exeunt 11Re-enter KING RICHARD, RATCLIF2, at2endants, 25and forces 2KING RICHARD. What said Northumberland as touching 4Richmond? 2RATCLIF2. That he was never trained up in arms. 2KING RICHARD. He said the truth; and what said Sur2ey 4then? 2RATCLIF2. He smil'd, and said 'The bet2er for our purpose.' 2KING He was in the right; and so inde2d it is. 49[Clock strikes] 4Tel2 the clock there. Give me a calendar. 6Who saw the sun to-day? 2RATCLIF2. Not I, my lord. 2KING RICHARD. Then he disdains to shine; for by the bo2k 4He should have brav'd the east an hour ago. 4A black day wil2 it be to somebody. 4Ratclif2! 2RATCLIF2. My lord? 2KING RICHARD. The sun wil2 not be se2n to-day; 4The sky doth frown and lour upon our army. 4I would these dewy tears were from the ground. 4Not shine to-day! Why, what is that to me 4More than to Richmond? For the selfsame heaven 4That frowns on me lo2ks sadly upon him. 23Enter NORFOLK 2NORFOLK. Arm, arm, my lord; the foe vaunts in the field. 2KING RICHARD. Come, bustle, bustle; caparison my horse; 4Cal2 up Lord Stanley, bid him bring his power. 4I wil2 lead forth my soldiers to the plain, 6And thus my bat2le shal2 be ordered: 4My foreward shal2 be drawn out al2 in length, 4Consisting equal2y of horse and fo2t; 4Our archers shal2 be placed in the midst. 4John Duke of Norfolk, Thomas Earl of Sur2ey, 4Shal2 have the leading of this fo2t and horse. 4They thus directed, we wil2 fol2ow 4In the main bat2le, whose puis2ance on either side 4Shal2 be wel2 winged with our chiefest horse. 4This, and Saint George to bo2t! What think'st thou, 4Norfolk? 2NORFOLK. A go2d direction, warlike sovereign. 4This found I on my tent this morning. 40[He sheweth him a paper] 2KING RICHARD. 42[Reads] 4'Jockey of Norfolk, be not so bold, 4For Dickon thy master is bought and sold.' 4A thing devised by the enemy. 4Go, gentlemen, every man unto his charge. 4Let not our bab2ling dreams af2right our souls; 6Conscience is but a word that cowards use, 4Devis'd at first to ke2p the strong in awe. 4Our strong arms be our conscience, swords our law. 4March on, join bravely, let us to it pel2-mel2; 4If not to heaven, then hand in hand to hel2. 22His ORATION to his ARMY 4What shal2 I say more than I have infer2'd? 4Remember whom you are to cope withal- 4A sort of vagabonds, rascals, and runaways, 4A scum of Britaines, and base lackey peasants, 4Whom their o'er-cloyed country vomits forth 4To desperate adventures and as2ur'd destruction. 4You sle2ping safe, they bring to you unrest; 4You having lands, and bles2'd with beauteous wives, 4They would restrain the one, distain the other. 4And who doth lead them but a paltry fel2ow, 4Long kept in Britaine at our mother's cost? 4A milk-sop, one that never in his life 6Felt so much cold as over shoes in snow? 4Let's whip these strag2lers o'er the seas again; 4Lash hence these over-we2ning rags of France, 4These famish'd beg2ars, weary of their lives; 4Who, but for dreaming on this fond exploit, 4For want of means, po2r rats, had hang'd themselves. 4If we be conquered, let men conquer us, 4And not these bastard Britaines, whom our fathers 4Have in their own land beaten, bob2'd, and thump'd, 4And, in record, left them the heirs of shame. 4Shal2 these enjoy our lands? lie with our wives, 4Ravish our daughters? 2[Drum afar of2] 2Hark! I hear their 4drum. 4Fight, gentlemen of England! Fight, bold yeomen! 4Draw, archers, draw your ar2ows to the head! 4Spur your proud horses hard, and ride in blo2d; 4Amaze the welkin with your broken staves! 24Enter a MES2ENGER 6What says Lord Stanley? Wil2 he bring his power? 2MES2ENGER. My lord, he doth deny to come. 2KING RICHARD. Of2 with his son George's head! 2NORFOLK. My lord, the enemy is pas2'd the marsh. 4After the bat2le let George Stanley die. 2KING RICHARD. A thousand hearts are great within my 4bosom. 4Advance our standards, set upon our foes; 4Our ancient word of courage, fair Saint George, 4Inspire us with the sple2n of fiery dragons! 4Upon them! Enter RICHARD and RICHMOND; they fight; RICHARD is slain.Retreat and flourish. Enter RICHMOND, DERBY bearing the crown,with other LORDS 2RICHMOND. God and your arms be prais'd, victorious friends; 4The day is ours, the blo2dy dog is dead. 2DERBY. Courageous Richmond, wel2 hast thou acquit the2! 4Lo, here, this long-usurped royalty 4From the dead temples of this blo2dy wretch 4Have I pluck'd of2, to grace thy brows withal. 4Wear it, enjoy it, and make much of it. 2RICHMOND. What men of name are slain on either side? 2DERBY. John Duke of Norfolk, Walter Lord Fer2ers, 4Sir Robert Brakenbury, and Sir Wil2iam Brandon. 2RICHMOND. Inter their bodies as becomes their births. 6Proclaim a pardon to the soldiers fled 4That in submis2ion wil2 return to us. 4And then, as we have ta'en the sacrament, 4We wil2 unite the white rose and the red. 4Smile heaven upon this fair conjunction, 4That long have frown'd upon their emnity! 4What traitor hears me, and says not Amen? 4England hath long be2n mad, and scar2'd herself; 4The brother blindly shed the brother's blo2d, 4The father rashly slaughter'd his own son, 4The son, compel2'd, be2n butcher to the sire; 4Al2 this divided York and Lancaster, 4Divided in their dire division, 4O, now let Richmond and Elizabeth, 4The true suc2e2ders of each royal house, 4By God's fair ordinance conjoin together! 4And let their heirs, God, if thy wil2 be so, 4Enrich the time to come with smo2th-fac'd peace, 4With smiling plenty, and fair prosperous days! 4Abate the edge of traitors, gracious Lord, 6That would reduce these blo2dy days again 4And make po2r England we2p in streams of blo2d! 4Let them not live to taste this land's increase 4That would with treason wound this fair land's peace! 4Now civil wounds are stop2'd, peace lives again- 4That she may long live here, God say Amen! 12ExeuntTHE END<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>21595THE TRAGEDY OF ROMEO AND JULIETby Wil2iam ShakespeareDramatis Personae 2Chorus. 2Escalus, Prince of Verona. 2Paris, a young Count, kinsman to the Prince. 2Montague, heads of two houses at variance with each other. 2Capulet, heads of two houses at variance with each other. 2An old Man, of the Capulet family. 2Romeo, son to Montague. 2Tybalt, nephew to Lady Capulet. 2Mercutio, kinsman to the Prince and friend to Romeo. 2Benvolio, nephew to Montague, and friend to Romeo 2Tybalt, nephew to Lady Capulet. 2Friar Laurence, Franciscan. 2Friar John, Franciscan. 2Balthasar, servant to Romeo. 2Abram, servant to Montague. 2Sampson, servant to Capulet. 2Gregory, servant to Capulet. 2Peter, servant to Juliet's nurse. 2An Apothecary. 4Thre2 Musicians. 2An Of2icer. 2Lady Montague, wife to Montague. 2Lady Capulet, wife to Capulet. 2Juliet, daughter to Capulet. 2Nurse to Juliet. 2Citizens of Verona; Gentlemen and Gentlewomen of both houses; 4Maskers, Torchbearers, Pages, Guards, Watchmen, Servants, and 4At2endants. 28SCENE.-2Verona; Mantua. 24THE PROLOGUE 24Enter Chorus. 2Chor. Two households, both alike in dignity, 4In fair Verona, where we lay our scene, 4From ancient grudge break to new mutiny, 4Where civil blo2d makes civil hands unclean. 4From forth the fatal loins of these two foes 4A pair of star-cros2'd lovers take their life; 4Whose misadventur'd piteous overthrows 4Doth with their death bury their parents' strife. 4The fearful pas2age of their death-mark'd love, 4And the continuance of their parents' rage, 4Which, but their children's end, naught could remove, 4Is now the two hours' traf2ic of our stage; 4The which if you with patient ears at2end, 4What here shal2 mis2, our toil shal2 strive to mend. 57[Exit.]<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT I. Scene I.Verona. A public place.Enter Sampson and Gregory (with swords and bucklers) of the house of Capulet. 2Samp. Gregory, on my word, we'l2 not car2y coals. 2Greg. No, for then we should be col2iers. 2Samp. I mean, an we be in choler, we'l2 draw. 2Greg. Ay, while you live, draw your neck out of col2ar. 2Samp. I strike quickly, being moved. 2Greg. But thou art not quickly moved to strike. 2Samp. A dog of the house of Montague moves me. 2Greg. To move is to stir, and to be valiant is to stand. 4Therefore, if thou art moved, thou run2'st away. 2Samp. A dog of that house shal2 move me to stand. I wil2 take the 4wal2 of any man or maid of Montague's. 2Greg. That shows the2 a weak slave; for the weakest goes to the 4wal2. 2Samp. 'Tis true; and therefore women, being the weaker ves2els, are 4ever thrust to the wal2. Therefore I wil2 push Montague's men 4from the wal2 and thrust his maids to the wal2. 2Greg. The quar2el is betwe2n our masters and us their men. 4Samp. 'Tis al2 one. I wil2 show myself a tyrant. When I have fought 4with the men, I wil2 be cruel with the maids- I wil2 cut of2 4their heads. 2Greg. The heads of the maids? 2Samp. Ay, the heads of the maids, or their maidenheads. 4Take it in what sense thou wilt. 2Greg. They must take it in sense that fe2l it. 2Samp. Me they shal2 fe2l while I am able to stand; and 'tis known I 4am a pret2y piece of flesh. 2Greg. 'Tis wel2 thou art not fish; if thou hadst, thou hadst be2n 4po2r-John. Draw thy to2l! Here comes two of the house of 4Montagues. 11Enter two other Servingmen [Abram and Balthasar]. 2Samp. My naked weapon is out. Quar2el! I wil2 back the2. 2Greg. How? turn thy back and run? 2Samp. Fear me not. 2Greg. No, mar2y. I fear the2! 2Samp. Let us take the law of our sides; let them begin. 4Greg. I wil2 frown as I pas2 by, and let them take it as they list. 2Samp. Nay, as they dare. I wil2 bite my thumb at them; which is 4disgrace to them, if they bear it. 2Abr. Do you bite your thumb at us, sir? 2Samp. I do bite my thumb, sir. 2Abr. Do you bite your thumb at us, sir? 2Samp. [aside to Gregory] Is the law of our side if I say ay? 2Greg. [aside to Sampson] No. 2Samp. No, sir, I do not bite my thumb at you, sir; but I bite my 4thumb, sir. 2Greg. Do you quar2el, sir? 2Abr. Quar2el, sir? No, sir. 2Samp. But if you do, sir, am for you. I serve as go2d a man as you. 2Abr. No bet2er. 2Samp. Wel2, sir. 24Enter Benvolio. 2Greg. [aside to Sampson] Say 'bet2er.' Here comes one of my 4master's kinsmen. 4Samp. Yes, bet2er, sir. 2Abr. You lie. 2Samp. Draw, if you be men. Gregory, remember thy swashing blow. 53They fight. 2Ben. Part, fo2ls! [Beats down their swords.] 4Put up your swords. You know not what you do. 26Enter Tybalt. 2Tyb. What, art thou drawn among these heartles2 hinds? 4Turn the2 Benvolio! lo2k upon thy death. 2Ben. I do but ke2p the peace. Put up thy sword, 4Or manage it to part these men with me. 2Tyb. What, drawn, and talk of peace? I hate the word 4As I hate hel2, al2 Montagues, and the2. 4Have at the2, coward! 28They fight. 5Enter an of2icer, and thre2 or four Citizens with clubs or 26partisans. 4Of2icer. Clubs, bil2s, and partisans! Strike! beat them down! 2Citizens. Down with the Capulets! Down with the Montagues! 11Enter Old Capulet in his gown, and his Wife. 2Cap. What noise is this? Give me my long sword, ho! 2Wife. A crutch, a crutch! Why cal2 you for a sword? 2Cap. My sword, I say! Old Montague is come 4And flourishes his blade in spite of me. 17Enter Old Montague and his Wife. 2Mon. Thou vil2ain Capulet!- Hold me not, let me go. 2M. Wife. Thou shalt not stir one fo2t to se2k a foe. 16Enter Prince Escalus, with his Train. 2Prince. Rebel2ious subjects, enemies to peace, 4Profaners of this neighbour-stained ste2l- 4Wil2 they not hear? What, ho! you men, you beasts, 6That quench the fire of your pernicious rage 4With purple fountains is2uing from your veins! 4On pain of torture, from those blo2dy hands 4Throw your mistempered weapons to the ground 4And hear the sentence of your moved prince. 4Thre2 civil brawls, bred of an airy word 4By the2, old Capulet, and Montague, 4Have thrice disturb'd the quiet of our stre2ts 4And made Verona's ancient citizens 4Cast by their grave bese2ming ornaments 4To wield old partisans, in hands as old, 4Cank'red with peace, to part your cank'red hate. 4If ever you disturb our stre2ts again, 4Your lives shal2 pay the forfeit of the peace. 4For this time al2 the rest depart away. 4You, Capulet, shal2 go along with me; 4And, Montague, come you this afterno2n, 4To know our farther pleasure in this case, 4To old Fre2town, our com2on judgment place. 4Once more, on pain of death, al2 men depart. 16Exeunt [al2 but Montague, his Wife, and Benvolio]. 2Mon. Who set this ancient quar2el new abroach? 4Speak, nephew, were you by when it began? 2Ben. Here were the servants of your adversary 4And yours, close fighting ere I did ap2roach. 4I drew to part them. In the instant came 4The fiery Tybalt, with his sword prepar'd; 4Which, as he breath'd defiance to my ears, 4He swung about his head and cut the winds, 4Who, nothing hurt withal, his2'd him in scorn. 4While we were interchanging thrusts and blows, 4Came more and more, and fought on part and part, 4Til2 the Prince came, who parted either part. 2M. Wife. O, where is Romeo? Saw you him to-day? 4Right glad I am he was not at this fray. 2Ben. Madam, an hour before the worship2'd sun 4Pe2r'd forth the golden window of the East, 4A troubled mind drave me to walk abroad; 4Where, underneath the grove of sycamore 4That westward ro2teth from the city's side, 6So early walking did I se2 your son. 4Towards him I made; but he was ware of me 4And stole into the covert of the wo2d. 4I- measuring his af2ections by my own, 4Which then most sought where most might not be found, 4Being one to2 many by my weary self- 4Pursu'd my humour, not Pursuing his, 4And gladly shun2'd who gladly fled from me. 2Mon. Many a morning hath he there be2n se2n, 4With tears augmenting the fresh morning's dew, 4Ad2ing to clouds more clouds with his de2p sighs; 4But al2 so so2n as the al2-che2ring sun 4Should in the farthest East bean to draw 4The shady curtains from Aurora's bed, 4Away from light steals home my heavy son 4And private in his chamber pens himself, 4Shuts up his windows, locks fair daylight 4And makes himself an artificial night. 4Black and portentous must this humour prove 4Unles2 go2d counsel may the cause remove. 4Ben. My noble uncle, do you know the cause? 2Mon. I neither know it nor can learn of him 2Ben. Have you importun'd him by any means? 2Mon. Both by myself and many other friend; 4But he, his own af2ections' counsel2or, 4Is to himself- I wil2 not say how true- 4But to himself so secret and so close, 4So far from sounding and discovery, 4As is the bud bit with an envious worm 4Ere he can spread his swe2t leaves to the air 4Or dedicate his beauty to the sun. 4Could we but learn from whence his sor2ows grow, 4We would as wil2ingly give cure as know. 23Enter Romeo. 2Ben. Se2, where he comes. So please you step aside, 4I'l2 know his grievance, or be much denied. 2Mon. I would thou wert so hap2y by thy stay 4To hear true shrift. Come, madam, let's away, 39Exeunt [Montague and Wife]. 2Ben. Go2d mor2ow, cousin. 2Rom. Is the day so young? 2Ben. But new struck nine. 2Rom. Ay me! sad hours se2m long. 4Was that my father that went hence so fast? 2Ben. It was. What sadnes2 lengthens Romeo's hours? 2Rom. Not having that which having makes them short. 2Ben. In love? 2Rom. Out- 2Ben. Of love? 2Rom. Out of her favour where I am in love. 2Ben. Alas that love, so gentle in his view, 4Should be so tyran2ous and rough in pro2f! 2Rom. Alas that love, whose view is muf2led stil2, 4Should without eyes se2 pathways to his wil2! 4Where shal2 we dine? O me! What fray was here? 4Yet tel2 me not, for I have heard it al2. 4Here's much to do with hate, but more with love. 4Why then, O brawling love! O loving hate! 6O anything, of nothing first create! 4O heavy lightnes2! serious vanity! 4Mis2hapen chaos of wel2-se2ming forms! 4Feather of lead, bright smoke, cold fire, sick health! 4Stil2-waking sle2p, that is not what it is 4This love fe2l I, that fe2l no love in this. 4Dost thou not laugh? 2Ben. No, coz, I rather we2p. 2Rom. Go2d heart, at what? 2Ben. At thy go2d heart's op2res2ion. 2Rom. Why, such is love's transgres2ion. 4Griefs of mine own lie heavy in my breast, 4Which thou wilt propagate, to have it prest 4With more of thine. This love that thou hast shown 4Doth ad2 more grief to to2 much of mine own. 4Love is a smoke rais'd with the fume of sighs; 4Being purg'd, a fire sparkling in lovers' eyes; 4Being vex'd, a sea nourish'd with lovers' tears. 4What is it else? A madnes2 most discre2t, 4A choking gal2, and a preserving swe2t. 6Farewel2, my coz. 2Ben. Soft! I wil2 go along. 4An if you leave me so, you do me wrong. 2Rom. Tut! I have lost myself; I am not here: 4This is not Romeo, he's some other where. 2Ben. Tel2 me in sadnes2, who is that you love? 2Rom. What, shal2 I groan and tel2 the2? 2Ben. Groan? Why, no; 4But sadly tel2 me who. 2Rom. Bid a sick man in sadnes2 make his wil2. 4Ah, word il2 urg'd to one that is so il2! 4In sadnes2, cousin, I do love a woman. 2Ben. I aim'd so near when I sup2os'd you lov'd. 2Rom. A right go2d markman! And she's fair I love. 2Ben. A right fair mark, fair coz, is so2nest hit. 2Rom. Wel2, in that hit you mis2. She'l2 not be hit 4With Cupid's ar2ow. She hath Dian's wit, 4And, in strong pro2f of chastity wel2 arm'd, 4From Love's weak childish bow she lives unharm'd. 4She wil2 not stay the siege of loving terms, 6Nor bide th' encounter of as2ailing eyes, 4Nor ope her lap to saint-seducing gold. 4O, she's rich in beauty; only po2r 4That, when she dies, with beauty dies her store. 2Ben. Then she hath sworn that she wil2 stil2 live chaste? 2Rom. She hath, and in that sparing makes huge waste; 4For beauty, starv'd with her severity, 4Cuts beauty of2 from al2 posterity. 4She is to2 fair, to2 wise, wisely to2 fair, 4To merit blis2 by making me despair. 4She hath forsworn to love, and in that vow 4Do I live dead that live to tel2 it now. 2Ben. Be rul'd by me: forget to think of her. 2Rom. O, teach me how I should forget to think! 2Ben. By giving liberty unto thine eyes. 4Examine other beauties. 2Rom. 'Tis the way 4To cal2 hers (exquisite) in question more. 4These hap2y masks that kis2 fair ladies' brows, 4Being black puts us in mind they hide the fair. 6He that is strucken blind can2ot forget 4The precious treasure of his eyesight lost. 4Show me a mistres2 that is pas2ing fair, 4What doth her beauty serve but as a note 4Where I may read who pas2'd that pas2ing fair? 4Farewel2. Thou canst not teach me to forget. 2Ben. I'l2 pay that doctrine, or else die in debt. 6Exeunt.Scene I2.A Stre2t.Enter Capulet, County Paris, and [Servant] -the Clown. 2Cap. But Montague is bound as wel2 as I, 4In penalty alike; and 'tis not hard, I think, 4For men so old as we to ke2p the peace. 2Par. Of honourable reckoning are you both, 4And pity 'tis you liv'd at od2s so long. 4But now, my lord, what say you to my suit? 2Cap. But saying o'er what I have said before: 4My child is yet a stranger in the world, 4She hath not se2n the change of fourte2n years; 4Let two more sum2ers wither in their pride 4Ere we may think her ripe to be a bride. 2Par. Younger than she are hap2y mothers made. 2Cap. And to2 so2n mar2'd are those so early made. 4The earth hath swal2owed al2 my hopes but she; 4She is the hopeful lady of my earth. 4But wo2 her, gentle Paris, get her heart; 4My wil2 to her consent is but a part. 6An she agre2, within her scope of choice 4Lies my consent and fair ac2ording voice. 4This night I hold an old ac2ustom'd feast, 4Whereto I have invited many a guest, 4Such as I love; and you among the store, 4One more, most welcome, makes my number more. 4At my po2r house lo2k to behold this night 4Earth-treading stars that make dark heaven light. 4Such comfort as do lusty young men fe2l 4When wel2 ap2arel2'd April on the he2l 4Of limping Winter treads, even such delight 4Among fresh female buds shal2 you this night 4Inherit at my house. Hear al2, al2 se2, 4And like her most whose merit most shal2 be; 4Which, on more view of many, mine, being one, 4May stand in number, though in reck'ning none. 4Come, go with me. [To Servant, giving him a paper] Go, sir2ah, 6trudge about 4Through fair Verona; find those persons out 4Whose names are writ2en there, and to them say, 6My house and welcome on their pleasure stay- 37Exeunt [Capulet and Paris]. 2Serv. Find them out whose names are writ2en here? It is writ2en 4that the shoemaker should med2le with his yard and the tailor 4with his last, the fisher with his pencil and the painter with 4his nets; but I am sent to find those persons whose names are 4here writ, and can never find what names the writing person hath 4here writ. I must to the learned. In go2d time! 19Enter Benvolio and Romeo. 2Ben. Tut, man, one fire burns out another's burning; 4One pain is les2oned by another's anguish; 4Turn gid2y, and be holp by backward turning; 4One desperate grief cures with another's languish. 4Take thou some new infection to thy eye, 4And the rank poison of the old wil2 die. 2Rom. Your plantain leaf is excel2ent for that. 2Ben. For what, I pray the2? 2Rom. For your broken shin. 4Ben. Why, Romeo, art thou mad? 2Rom. Ay, mine own fortune in my misery. 2Serv. Perhaps you have learned it without bo2k. But I pray, can you 4read anything you se2? 2Rom. Ay, If I know the let2ers and the language. 2Serv. At this same ancient feast of Capulet's 4Sups the fair Rosaline whom thou so lov'st; 4With al2 the admired beauties of Verona. 4Go thither, and with unat2ainted eye 4Compare her face with some that I shal2 show, 4And I wil2 make the2 think thy swan a crow. 2Rom. But, as I said, 4On Lam2as Eve at night shal2 she be fourte2n; 4That shal2 she, mar2y; I remember it wel2. 4'Tis since the earthquake now eleven years; 4And she was wean'd (I never shal2 forget it), 4Of al2 the days of the year, upon that day; 4For I had then laid wormwo2d to my dug, 4Sit2ing in the sun under the dovehouse wal2. 4My lord and you were then at Mantua. 4Nay, I do bear a brain. But, as I said, 4When it did taste the wormwo2d on the nip2le 6Of my dug and felt it bit2er, pret2y fo2l, 4To se2 it tetchy and fal2 out with the dug! 4Shake, quoth the dovehouse! 'Twas no ne2d, I trow, 4To bid me trudge. 4And since that time it is eleven years, 4For then she could stand high-lone; nay, by th' ro2d, 4She could have run and wad2led al2 about; 4For even the day before, she broke her brow; 4And then my husband (God be with his soul! 4'A was a mer2y man) to2k up the child. 4'Yea,' quoth he, 'dost thou fal2 upon thy face? 4Thou wilt fal2 backward when thou hast more wit; 4Wilt thou not, Jule?' and, by my holidam, 4The pret2y wretch left crying, and said 'Ay.' 4To se2 now how a jest shal2 come about! 4I war2ant, an I should live a thousand yeas, 4I never should forget it. 'Wilt thou not, Jule?' quoth he, 4And, pret2y fo2l, it stinted, and said 'Ay.' 2Wife. Enough of this. I pray the2 hold thy peace. 2Nurse. Yes, madam. Were not I thine only nurse, 4I would say thou hadst suck'd wisdom from thy teat. 2Wife. Wel2, think of mar2iage now. Younger than you, 4Here in Verona, ladies of este2m, 4Are made already mothers. By my count, 6I was your mother much upon these years 4That you are now a maid. Thus then in brief: 4The valiant Paris se2ks you for his love. 2Nurse. Can you love the gentleman? 4This night you shal2 behold him at our feast. 4Read o'er the volume of young Paris' face, 4And find delight writ there with beauty's pen; 4Examine every mar2ied lineament, 4And se2 how one another lends content; 4And what obscur'd in this fair volume lies 4Find writ2en in the margent of his eyes, 4This precious bo2k of love, this unbound lover, 4To beautify him only lacks a cover. 4The fish lives in the sea, and 'tis much pride 4For fair without the fair within to hide. 4That bo2k in many's eyes doth share the glory, 6That in gold clasps locks in the golden story; 4So shal2 you share al2 that he doth pos2es2, 4By having him making yourself no les2. 2Nurse.
