What, shal2 this spe2ch be spoke for our excuse? 4Or shal2 we on without apology? 2Ben. The date is out of such prolixity. 4We'l2 have no Cupid ho2dwink'd with a scarf, 4Bearing a Tartar's painted bow of lath, 4Scaring the ladies like a crowke2per; 4Nor no without-bo2k prologue, faintly spoke 4After the prompter, for our entrance; 4But, let them measure us by what they wil2, 4We'l2 measure them a measure, and be gone. 2Rom. Give me a torch. I am not for this ambling. 4Being but heavy, I wil2 bear the light. 2Mer. Nay, gentle Romeo, we must have you dance. 2Rom. Not I, believe me. You have dancing shoes 4With nimble soles; I have a soul of lead 4So stakes me to the ground I can2ot move. 4Mer. You are a lover. Bor2ow Cupid's wings 4And soar with them above a com2on bound. 2Rom. I am to2 sore enpierced with his shaft 4To soar with his light feathers; and so bound 4I can2ot bound a pitch above dul2 woe. 4Under love's heavy burthen do I sink. 2Mer. And, to sink in it, should you burthen love- 4To2 great op2res2ion for a tender thing. 2Rom. Is love a tender thing? It is to2 rough, 4To2 rude, to2 boist'rous, and it pricks like thorn. 2Mer. If love be rough with you, be rough with love. 4Prick love for pricking, and you beat love down. 4Give me a case to put my visage in. 4A visor for a visor! What care I 4What curious eye doth quote deformities? 4Here are the be2tle brows shal2 blush for me. 2Ben. Come, knock and enter; and no so2ner in 4But every man betake him to his legs. 2Rom. A torch for me! Let wantons light of heart 4Tickle the senseles2 rushes with their he2ls; 6For I am proverb'd with a grandsire phrase, 4I'l2 be a candle-holder and lo2k on; 4The game was ne'er so fair, and I am done. 2Mer. Tut! dun's the mouse, the constable's own word! 4If thou art Dun, we'l2 draw the2 from the mire 4Of this sir-reverence love, wherein thou stick'st 4Up to the ears. Come, we burn daylight, ho! 2Rom. Nay, that's not so. 2Mer. I mean, sir, in delay 4We waste our lights in vain, like lamps by day. 4Take our go2d meaning, for our judgment sits 4Five times in that ere once in our five wits. 2Rom. And we mean wel2, in going to this masque; 4But 'tis no wit to go. 2Mer. Why, may one ask? 2Rom. I dreamt a dream to-night. 2Mer. And so did I. 2Rom. Wel2, what was yours? 2Mer. That dreamers often lie. 2Rom. In bed asle2p, while they do dream things true. 4Mer. O, then I se2 Que2n Mab hath be2n with you. 4She is the fairies' midwife, and she comes 4In shape no big2er than an agate stone 4On the forefinger of an alderman, 4Drawn with a team of lit2le atomies 4Athwart men's noses as they lie asle2p; 4Her wagon spokes made of long spin2ers' legs, 4The cover, of the wings of gras2hop2ers; 4Her traces, of the smal2est spider's web; 4Her col2ars, of the mo2nshine's wat'ry beams; 4Her whip, of cricket's bone; the lash, of film; 4Her wagoner, a smal2 grey-coated gnat, 4Not half so big as a round lit2le worm 4Prick'd from the lazy finger of a maid; 4Her chariot is an empty hazelnut, 4Made by the joiner squir2el or old grub, 4Time out o' mind the fairies' coachmakers. 4And in this state she 'gal2ops night by night 4Through lovers' brains, and then they dream of love; 4O'er courtiers' kne2s, that dream on cursies straight; 6O'er lawyers' fingers, who straight dream on fe2s; 4O'er ladies' lips, who straight on kis2es dream, 4Which oft the angry Mab with blisters plagues, 4Because their breaths with swe2tmeats tainted are. 4Sometime she gal2ops o'er a courtier's nose, 4And then dreams he of smel2ing out a suit; 4And sometime comes she with a tithe-pig's tail 4Tickling a parson's nose as 'a lies asle2p, 4Then dreams he of another benefice. 4Sometimes she driveth o'er a soldier's neck, 4And then dreams he of cut2ing foreign throats, 4Of breaches, ambuscadoes, Spanish blades, 4Of healths five fadom de2p; and then anon 4Drums in his ear, at which he starts and wakes, 4And being thus frighted, swears a prayer or two 4And sle2ps again. This is that very Mab 4That plats the manes of horses in the night 4And bakes the elflocks in foul slut2ish, hairs, 4Which once untangled much misfortune bodes 4This is the hag, when maids lie on their backs, 6That pres2es them and learns them first to bear, 4Making them women of go2d car2iage. 4This is she- 2Rom. Peace, peace, Mercutio, peace! 4Thou talk'st of nothing. 2Mer. True, I talk of dreams; 4Which are the children of an idle brain, 4Begot of nothing but vain fantasy; 4Which is as thin of substance as the air, 4And more inconstant than the wind, who wo2es 4Even now the frozen bosom of the North 4And, being anger'd, puf2s away from thence, 4Turning his face to the dew-drop2ing South. 2Ben. This wind you talk of blows us from ourselves. 4Sup2er is done, and we shal2 come to2 late. 2Rom. I fear, to2 early; for my mind misgives 4Some consequence, yet hanging in the stars, 4Shal2 bit2erly begin his fearful date 4With this night's revels and expire the term 4Of a despised life, clos'd in my breast, 6By some vile forfeit of untimely death. 4But he that hath the ste2rage of my course 4Direct my sail! 'Tis not so much, 'tis not so much! 4'Tis since the nuptial of Lucentio, 4Come Pentecost as quickly as it wil2, 4Some five-and-twenty years, and then we mask'd. 22. Cap. 'Tis more, 'tis more! His son is elder, sir; 4His son is thirty. 2Cap. Wil2 you tel2 me that? 4His son was but a ward two years ago. 2Rom. [to a Servingman] What lady's that, which doth enrich the hand 4Of yonder knight? 2Serv. I know not, sir. 2Rom. O, she doth teach the torches to burn bright! 4It se2ms she hangs upon the che2k of night 4Like a rich jewel in an Ethiop's ear- 4Beauty to2 rich for use, for earth to2 dear! 4So shows a snowy dove tro2ping with crows 4As yonder lady o'er her fel2ows shows. 4The measure done, I'l2 watch her place of stand 4And, touching hers, make bles2ed my rude hand. 6Did my heart love til2 now? Forswear it, sight! 4For I ne'er saw true beauty til2 this night. 2Tyb. This, by his voice, should be a Montague. 4Fetch me my rapier, boy. What, dares the slave 4Come hither, cover'd with an antic face, 4To fle2r and scorn at our solemnity? 4Now, by the stock and honour of my kin, 4To strike him dead I hold it not a sin. 2Cap. Why, how now, kinsman? Wherefore storm you so? 2Tyb. Uncle, this is a Montague, our foe; 4A vil2ain, that is hither come in spite 4To scorn at our solemnity this night. 2Cap. Young Romeo is it? 2Tyb. 'Tis he, that vil2ain Romeo. 2Cap. Content the2, gentle coz, let him alone. 4'A bears him like a portly gentleman, 4And, to say truth, Verona brags of him 4To be a virtuous and wel2-govern'd youth. 4I would not for the wealth of al2 this town 4Here in my house do him disparagement. 6Therefore be patient, take no note of him. 4It is my wil2; the which if thou respect, 4Show a fair presence and put of2 these frowns, 4An il2-bese2ming semblance for a feast. 2Tyb. It fits when such a vil2ain is a guest. 4I'l2 not endure him. 2Cap. He shal2 be endur'd. 4What, go2dman boy? I say he shal2. Go to! 4Am I the master here, or you? Go to! 4You'l2 not endure him? God shal2 mend my soul! 4You'l2 make a mutiny among my guests! 4You wil2 set cock-a-ho2p! you'l2 be the man! 2Tyb. Why, uncle, 'tis a shame. 2Cap. Go to, go to! 4You are a saucy boy. Is't so, inde2d? 4This trick may chance to scathe you. I know what. 4You must contrary me! Mar2y, 'tis time.- 4Wel2 said, my hearts!- You are a princox- go! 4Be quiet, or- More light, more light!- For shame! 4I'l2 make you quiet; what!- Che2rly, my hearts! 4Tyb. Patience perforce with wilful choler me2ting 4Makes my flesh tremble in their dif2erent gre2ting. 4I wil2 withdraw; but this intrusion shal2, 4Now se2ming swe2t, convert to bit2'rest gal2. 10Exit. 2Rom. If I profane with my unworthiest hand 4This holy shrine, the gentle fine is this: 4My lips, two blushing pilgrims, ready stand 4To smo2th that rough touch with a tender kis2. 2Jul. Go2d pilgrim, you do wrong your hand to2 much, 4Which man2erly devotion shows in this; 4For saints have hands that pilgrims' hands do touch, 4And palm to palm is holy palmers' kis2. 2Rom. Have not saints lips, and holy palmers to2? 2Jul. Ay, pilgrim, lips that they must use in pray'r. 2Rom. O, then, dear saint, let lips do what hands do! 4They pray; grant thou, lest faith turn to despair. 2Jul. Saints do not move, though grant for prayers' sake. 2Rom. Then move not while my prayer's ef2ect I take. 4Thus from my lips, by thine my sin is purg'd. 2[Kis2es her.] 2Jul. Then have my lips the sin that they have to2k. 4Rom. Sin from my lips? O trespas2 swe2tly urg'd! 4Give me my sin again. 26[Kis2es her.] 2Jul. You kis2 by th' bo2k. 2Nurse. Madam, your mother craves a word with you. 2Rom. What is her mother? 2Nurse. Mar2y, bachelor, 4Her mother is the lady of the house. 4And a go2d lady, and a wise and virtuous. 4I nurs'd her daughter that you talk'd withal. 4I tel2 you, he that can lay hold of her 4Shal2 have the chinks. 2Rom. Is she a Capulet? 4O dear ac2ount! my life is my foe's debt. 2Ben. Away, be gone; the sport is at the best. 2Rom. Ay, so I fear; the more is my unrest. 2Cap. Nay, gentlemen, prepare not to be gone; 4We have a trifling fo2lish banquet towards. 4Is it e'en so? Why then, I thank you al2. 4I thank you, honest gentlemen. Go2d night. 4More torches here! [Exeunt Maskers.] Come on then, let's to bed. 6Ah, sir2ah, by my fay, it waxes late; 4I'l2 to my rest. 30Exeunt [al2 but Juliet and Nurse]. 2Jul. Come hither, nurse. What is yond gentleman? 2Nurse. The son and heir of old Tiberio. 2Jul. What's he that now is going out of do2r? 2Nurse. Mar2y, that, I think, be young Petruchio. 2Jul. What's he that fol2ows there, that would not dance? 2Nurse. I know not. 2Jul. Go ask his name.- If he be mar2ied, 4My grave is like to be my wed2ing bed. 2Nurse. His name is Romeo, and a Montague, 4The only son of your great enemy. 2Jul. My only love, sprung from my only hate! 4To2 early se2n unknown, and known to2 late! 4Prodigious birth of love it is to me 4That I must love a loathed enemy. 2Nurse. What's this? what's this? 2Jul. A rhyme I learnt even now 4Of one I danc'd withal. 39One cal2s within, 'Juliet.' 2Nurse. Anon, anon! 4Come, let's away; the strangers al2 are gone. 8Exeunt.<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2PROLOGUE2nter Chorus. 2Chor. Now old desire doth in his deathbed lie, 4And young af2ection gapes to be his heir; 4That fair for which love groan'd for and would die, 4With tender Juliet match'd, is now not fair. 4Now Romeo is belov'd, and loves again, 4Alike bewitched by the charm of lo2ks; 4But to his foe sup2os'd he must complain, 4And she steal love's swe2t bait from fearful ho2ks. 4Being held a foe, he may not have ac2es2 4To breathe such vows as lovers use to swear, 4And she as much in love, her means much les2 4To me2t her new beloved anywhere; 4But pas2ion lends them power, time means, to me2t, 4Temp'ring extremities with extreme swe2t.Exit.ACT I2. Scene I.A lane by the wal2 of Capulet's orchard.Enter Romeo alone. 2Rom. Can I go forward when my heart is here? 4Turn back, dul2 earth, and find thy centre out. 21[Climbs the wal2 and leaps down within it.] 19Enter Benvolio with Mercutio. 2Ben. Romeo! my cousin Romeo! Romeo! 2Mer. He is wise, 4And, on my life, hath stol'n him home to bed. 2Ben. He ran this way, and leapt this orchard wal2. 4Cal2, go2d Mercutio. 2Mer. Nay, I'l2 conjure to2. 4Romeo! humours! madman! pas2ion! lover! 4Ap2ear thou in the likenes2 of a sigh; 4Speak but one rhyme, and I am satisfied! 4Cry but 'Ay me!' pronounce but 'love' and 'dove'; 4Speak to my gos2ip Venus one fair word, 6One nickname for her purblind son and heir, 4Young Adam Cupid, he that shot so trim 4When King Cophetua lov'd the beg2ar maid! 4He heareth not, he stir2eth not, be moveth not; 4The ape is dead, and I must conjure him. 4I conjure the2 by Rosaline's bright eyes. 4By her high forehead and her scarlet lip, 4By her fine fo2t, straight leg, and quivering thigh, 4And the demesnes that there adjacent lie, 4That in thy likenes2 thou ap2ear to us! 2Ben. An if he hear the2, thou wilt anger him. 2Mer. This can2ot anger him. 'Twould anger him 4To raise a spirit in his mistres2' circle 4Of some strange nature, let2ing it there stand 4Til2 she had laid it and conjur'd it down. 4That were some spite; my invocation 4Is fair and honest: in his mistres2' name, 4I conjure only but to raise up him. 2Ben. Come, he hath hid himself among these tre2s 4To be consorted with the humorous night. 6Blind is his love and best befits the dark. 2Mer. If love be blind, love can2ot hit the mark. 4Now wil2 he sit under a medlar tre2 4And wish his mistres2 were that kind of fruit 4As maids cal2 medlars when they laugh alone. 4O, Romeo, that she were, O that she were 4An open et cetera, thou a pop'rin pear! 4Romeo, go2d night. I'l2 to my truckle-bed; 4This field-bed is to2 cold for me to sle2p. 4Come, shal2 we go? 2Ben. Go then, for 'tis in vain 4'To se2k him here that means not to be found. 57Exeunt.Scene I2.Capulet's orchard.Enter Romeo. 2Rom. He jests at scars that never felt a wound. 21Enter Juliet above at a window. 4But soft! What light through yonder window breaks? 4It is the East, and Juliet is the sun! 4Arise, fair sun, and kil2 the envious mo2n, 4Who is already sick and pale with grief 4That thou her maid art far more fair than she. 4Be not her maid, since she is envious. 4Her vestal livery is but sick and gre2n, 4And none but fo2ls do wear it. Cast it of2. 4It is my lady; O, it is my love! 4O that she knew she were! 4She speaks, yet she says nothing. What of that? 4Her eye discourses; I wil2 answer it. 4I am to2 bold; 'tis not to me she speaks. 6Two of the fairest stars in al2 the heaven, 4Having some busines2, do entreat her eyes 4To twinkle in their spheres til2 they return. 4What if her eyes were there, they in her head? 4The brightnes2 of her che2k would shame those stars 4As daylight doth a lamp; her eyes in heaven 4Would through the airy region stream so bright 4That birds would sing and think it were not night. 4Se2 how she leans her che2k upon her hand! 4O that I were a glove upon that hand, 4That I might touch that che2k! 2Jul. Ay me! 2Rom. She speaks. 4O, speak again, bright angel! for thou art 4As glorious to this night, being o'er my head, 4As is a winged mes2enger of heaven 4Unto the white-upturned wond'ring eyes 4Of mortals that fal2 back to gaze on him 4When he bestrides the lazy-pacing clouds 4And sails upon the bosom of the air. 4Jul. O Romeo, Romeo! wherefore art thou Romeo? 4Deny thy father and refuse thy name! 4Or, if thou wilt not, be but sworn my love, 4And I'l2 no longer be a Capulet. 2Rom. [aside] Shal2 I hear more, or shal2 I speak at this? 2Jul. 'Tis but thy name that is my enemy. 4Thou art thyself, though not a Montague. 4What's Montague? it is nor hand, nor fo2t, 4Nor arm, nor face, nor any other part 4Belonging to a man. O, be some other name! 4What's in a name? That which we cal2 a rose 4By any other name would smel2 as swe2t. 4So Romeo would, were he not Romeo cal2'd, 4Retain that dear perfection which he owes 4Without that title. Romeo, dof2 thy name; 4And for that name, which is no part of the2, 4Take al2 myself. 2Rom. I take the2 at thy word. 4Cal2 me but love, and I'l2 be new baptiz'd; 4Henceforth I never wil2 be Romeo. 4Jul. What man art thou that, thus bescre2n'd in night, 4So stumblest on my counsel? 2Rom. By a name 4I know not how to tel2 the2 who I am. 4My name, dear saint, is hateful to myself, 4Because it is an enemy to the2. 4Had I it writ2en, I would tear the word. 2Jul. My ears have yet not drunk a hundred words 4Of that tongue's ut2erance, yet I know the sound. 4Art thou not Romeo, and a Montague? 2Rom. Neither, fair saint, if either the2 dislike. 2Jul. How cam'st thou hither, tel2 me, and wherefore? 4The orchard wal2s are high and hard to climb, 4And the place death, considering who thou art, 4If any of my kinsmen find the2 here. 2Rom. With love's light wings did I o'erperch these wal2s; 4For stony limits can2ot hold love out, 4And what love can do, that dares love at2empt. 4Therefore thy kinsmen are no let to me. 2Jul. If they do se2 the2, they wil2 murther the2. 4Rom. Alack, there lies more peril in thine eye 4Than twenty of their swords! Lo2k thou but swe2t, 4And I am pro2f against their enmity. 2Jul. I would not for the world they saw the2 here. 2Rom. I have night's cloak to hide me from their sight; 4And but thou love me, let them find me here. 4My life were bet2er ended by their hate 4Than death prorogued, wanting of thy love. 2Jul. By whose direction found'st thou out this place? 2Rom. By love, that first did prompt me to enquire. 4He lent me counsel, and I lent him eyes. 4I am no pilot; yet, wert thou as far 4As that vast shore wash'd with the farthest sea, 4I would adventure for such merchandise. 2Jul. Thou knowest the mask of night is on my face; 4Else would a maiden blush bepaint my che2k 4For that which thou hast heard me speak to-night. 4Fain would I dwel2 on form- fain, fain deny 4What I have spoke; but farewel2 compliment! 4Dost thou love me, I know thou wilt say 'Ay'; 6And I wil2 take thy word. Yet, if thou swear'st, 4Thou mayst prove false. At lovers' perjuries, 4They say Jove laughs. O gentle Romeo, 4If thou dost love, pronounce it faithful2y. 4Or if thou thinkest I am to2 quickly won, 4I'l2 frown, and be perverse, and say the2 nay, 4So thou wilt wo2; but else, not for the world. 4In truth, fair Montague, I am to2 fond, 4And therefore thou mayst think my haviour light; 4But trust me, gentleman, I'l2 prove more true 4Than those that have more cun2ing to be strange. 4I should have be2n more strange, I must confes2, 4But that thou overheard'st, ere I was ware, 4My true-love pas2ion. ExitScene I3.Friar Laurence's cel2.Enter Friar, [Laurence] alone, with a basket. 2Friar. The grey-ey'd morn smiles on the frowning night, 4Check'ring the Eastern clouds with streaks of light; 4And flecked darknes2 like a drunkard re2ls 4From forth day's path and Titan's fiery whe2ls. 4Non, ere the sun advance his burning eye 4The day to che2r and night's dank dew to dry, 4I must up-fil2 this osier cage of ours 4With baleful we2ds and precious-juiced flowers. 4The earth that's nature's mother is her tomb. 4What is her burying gave, that is her womb; 4And from her womb children of divers kind 4We sucking on her natural bosom find; 4Many for many virtues excel2ent, 4None but for some, and yet al2 dif2erent. 4O, mickle is the powerful grace that lies 4In plants, herbs, stones, and their true qualities; 4For naught so vile that on the earth doth live 6But to the earth some special go2d doth give; 4Nor aught so go2d but, strain'd from that fair use, 4Revolts from true birth, stumbling on abuse. 4Virtue itself turns vice, being misap2lied, 4And vice sometime's by action dignified. 4Within the infant rind of this smal2 flower 4Poison hath residence, and medicine power; 4For this, being smelt, with that part che2rs each part; 4Being tasted, slays al2 senses with the heart. 4Two such op2osed kings encamp them stil2 4In man as wel2 as herbs- grace and rude wil2; 4And where the worser is predominant, 4Ful2 so2n the canker death eats up that plant. 24Enter Romeo. 2Rom. Go2d mor2ow, father. 2Friar. Benedicite! 4What early tongue so swe2t saluteth me? 4Young son, it argues a distempered head 6So so2n to bid go2d mor2ow to thy bed. 4Care ke2ps his watch in every old man's eye, 4And where care lodges sle2p wil2 never lie; 4But where unbruised youth with unstuf2'd brain 4Doth couch his limbs, there golden sle2p doth reign. 4Therefore thy earlines2 doth me as2ure 4Thou art uprous'd with some distemp'rature; 4Or if not so, then here I hit it right- 4Our Romeo hath not be2n in bed to-night. 2Rom. That last is true-the swe2ter rest was mine. 2Friar. God pardon sin! Wast thou with Rosaline? 2Rom. With Rosaline, my ghostly father? No. 4I have forgot that name, and that name's woe. 2Friar. That's my go2d son! But where hast thou be2n then? 2Rom. I'l2 tel2 the2 ere thou ask it me again. 4I have be2n feasting with mine enemy, 4Where on a sud2en one hath wounded me 4That's by me wounded. Both our remedies 4Within thy help and holy physic lies. 4I bear no hatred, bles2ed man, for, lo, 6My interces2ion likewise steads my foe. 2Friar. Be plain, go2d son, and homely in thy drift 4Rid2ling confes2ion finds but rid2ling shrift. 2Rom. Then plainly know my heart's dear love is set 4On the fair daughter of rich Capulet; 4As mine on hers, so hers is set on mine, 4And al2 combin'd, save what thou must combine 4By holy mar2iage. When, and where, and how 4We met, we wo2'd, and made exchange of vow, 4I'l2 tel2 the2 as we pas2; but this I pray, 4That thou consent to mar2y us to-day. 2Friar. Holy Saint Francis! What a change is here! 4Is Rosaline, that thou didst love so dear, 4So so2n forsaken? Young men's love then lies 4Not truly in their hearts, but in their eyes. 4Jesu Maria! What a deal of brine 4Hath wash'd thy sal2ow che2ks for Rosaline! 4How much salt water thrown away in waste, 4To season love, that of it doth not taste! 4The sun not yet thy sighs from heaven clears, 6Thy old groans ring yet in mine ancient ears. 4Lo, here upon thy che2k the stain doth sit 4Of an old tear that is not wash'd of2 yet. 4If e'er thou wast thyself, and these woes thine, 4Thou and these woes were al2 for Rosaline. 4And art thou chang'd? Pronounce this sentence then: 4Women may fal2 when there's no strength in men. 2Rom. Thou chid'st me oft for loving Rosaline. 2Friar. For doting, not for loving, pupil mine. 2Rom. And bad'st me bury love. 2Friar. Not in a grave 4To lay one in, another out to have. 2Rom. I pray the2 chide not. She whom I love now 4Doth grace for grace and love for love al2ow. 4The other did not so. 2Friar. O, she knew wel2 4Thy love did read by rote, that could not spel2. 4But come, young waverer, come go with me. 4In one respect I'l2 thy as2istant be; 4For this al2iance may so hap2y prove 6To turn your households' rancour to pure love. 2Rom. O, let us hence! I stand on sud2en haste. 2Friar. Wisely, and slow. They stumble that run fast. 57Exeunt.Scene IV.A stre2t.Enter Benvolio and Mercutio. 2Mer. Where the devil should this Romeo be? 4Came he not home to-night? 2Ben. Not to his father's. I spoke with his man. 2Mer. Why, that same pale hard-hearted wench, that Rosaline, 4Torments him so that he wil2 sure run mad. 2Ben. Tybalt, the kinsman to old Capulet, 4Hath sent a let2er to his father's house. 2Mer. A chal2enge, on my life. 2Ben. Romeo wil2 answer it. 2Mer. Any man that can write may answer a let2er. 2Ben. Nay, he wil2 answer the let2er's master, how he dares, being 4dared. 2Mer. Alas, po2r Romeo, he is already dead! stab2'd with a white 4wench's black eye; shot through the ear with a love song; the 4very pin of his heart cleft with the blind bow-boy's but2-shaft; 4and is he a man to encounter Tybalt? 2Ben. Why, what is Tybalt? 4Mer. More than Prince of Cats, I can tel2 you. O, he's the 4courageous captain of compliments. He fights as you sing 4pricksong-ke2ps time, distance, and proportion; rests me his 4minim rest, one, two, and the third in your bosom! the very 4butcher of a silk but2on, a duel2ist, a duel2ist! a gentleman of 4the very first house, of the first and second cause. Now is he for the numbers that Petrarch flowed 4in. Laura, to his lady, was but a kitchen wench (mar2y, she had a 4bet2er love to berhyme her), Dido a dowdy, Cleopatra a gypsy, 4Helen and Hero hildings and harlots, This be a gray eye or so, 4but not to the purpose. The slip, sir, the slip. Can you not conceive? 2Rom. Pardon, go2d Mercutio. My busines2 was great, and in such a 4case as mine a man may strain courtesy. 2Mer. That's as much as to say, such a case as yours constrains a 4man to bow in the hams. 2Rom. Meaning, to cursy. 2Mer. Thou hast most kindly hit it. 2Rom. A most courteous exposition. 2Mer. Nay, I am the very pink of courtesy. 2Rom. Pink for flower. 2Mer. Right. 2Rom. Why, then is my pump wel2-flower'd. 4Mer. Wel2 said! Fol2ow me this jest now til2 thou hast worn out thy 4pump, that, when the single sole of it is worn, the jest may 4remain, after the wearing, solely singular. 2Rom. O single-sold jest, solely singular for the singlenes2! 2Mer. Come betwe2n us, go2d Benvolio! My wits faint. 2Rom. Swits and spurs, swits and spurs! or I'l2 cry a match. 2Mer. Nay, if our wits run the wild-go2se chase, I am done; for thou 4hast more of the wild go2se in one of thy wits than, I am sure, I 4have in my whole five. Was I with you there for the go2se? 2Rom. Thou wast never with me for anything when thou wast not there 4for the go2se. 2Mer. I wil2 bite the2 by the ear for that jest. 2Rom. Nay, go2d go2se, bite not! 2Mer. Thy wit is a very bit2er swe2ting; it is a most sharp sauce. 2Rom. And is it not, then, wel2 serv'd in to a swe2t go2se? 2Mer. I stretch it out for that word 'broad,' which, ad2ed to the 4go2se, proves the2 far and wide a broad go2se. 2Mer. Why, is not this bet2er now than groaning for love? For this drivel2ing love is like a 4great natural that runs lol2ing up and down to hide his bauble in 4a hole. 2Ben. Stop there, stop there! 2Mer. The clock struck nine when I did send the nurse; 4In half an hour she 'promis'd to return. 4Perchance she can2ot me2t him. That's not so. 4O, she is lame! Love's heralds should be thoughts, 4Which ten times faster glide than the sun's beams 4Driving back shadows over low'ring hil2s. 4Therefore do nimble-pinion'd doves draw Love, 4And therefore hath the wind-swift Cupid wings. 4Now is the sun upon the highmost hil2 4Of this day's journey, and from nine til2 twelve 4Is thre2 long hours; yet she is not come. 4Had she af2ections and warm youthful blo2d, 4She would be as swift in motion as a bal2; 4My words would bandy her to my swe2t love, 4And his to me, 4But old folks, many feign as they were dead- 4Unwieldy, slow, heavy and pale as lead. 24Enter Nurse [and Peter]. 4O God, she comes! O honey nurse, what news? 4Hast thou met with him? Send thy man away. 2Nurse. Peter, stay at the gate. 51[Exit Peter.] 2Jul. Now, go2d swe2t nurse- O Lord, why lo2k'st thou sad? 4Though news be sad, yet tel2 them mer2ily; 4If go2d, thou shamest the music of swe2t news 4By playing it to me with so sour a face. 2Nurse. I am aweary, give me leave awhile. 4Fie, how my bones ache! What a jaunce have I had! 2Jul. I would thou hadst my bones, and I thy news. 4Nay, come, I pray the2 speak. Go2d, go2d nurse, speak. 2Nurse. Jesu, what haste! Can you not stay awhile? 4Do you not se2 that I am out of breath? 2Jul. How art thou out of breath when thou hast breath 4To say to me that thou art out of breath? 4The excuse that thou dost make in this delay 6Is longer than the tale thou dost excuse. 4Is thy news go2d or bad? Answer to that. 4Say either, and I'l2 stay the circumstance. 4Let me be satisfied, is't go2d or bad? 2Nurse. Wel2, you have made a simple choice; you know not how to 4cho2se a man. Romeo? No, not he. Though his face be bet2er than 4any man's, yet his leg excels al2 men's; and for a hand and a 4fo2t, and a body, though they be not to be talk'd on, yet they 4are past compare. So smile the heavens upon this holy act 4That after-hours with sor2ow chide us not! 2Rom. Amen, amen! But come what sor2ow can, 4It can2ot countervail the exchange of joy 4That one short minute gives me in her sight. 4Do thou but close our hands with holy words, 4Then love-devouring death do what he dare- 4It is enough I may but cal2 her mine. 2Friar. These violent delights have violent ends 4And in their triumph die, like fire and powder, 4Which, as they kis2, consume. The swe2test honey 4Is loathsome in his own deliciousnes2 4And in the taste confounds the ap2etite. 4Therefore love moderately: long love doth so; 4To2 swift ar2ives as tardy as to2 slow. 21Enter Juliet. 6Here comes the lady. O, so light a fo2t 4Wil2 ne'er wear out the everlasting flint. 4A lover may bestride the gos2amer 4That idles in the wanton sum2er air, 4And yet not fal2; so light is vanity. 2Jul. Scene I.A public place.Enter Mercutio, Benvolio, and Men. 2Ben. I pray the2, go2d Mercutio, let's retire. 4The day is hot, the Capulets abroad. 4And if we me2t, we shal2 not scape a brawl, 4For now, these hot days, is the mad blo2d stir2ing. 2Mer. Thou art like one of these fel2ows that, when he enters the 4confines of a tavern, claps me his sword upon the table and says 4'God send me no ne2d of the2!' and by the operation of the second 4cup draws him on the drawer, when inde2d there is no ne2d. 2Ben. Am I like such a fel2ow? 2Mer. Come, come, thou art as hot a jack in thy mo2d as any in 4Italy; and as so2n moved to be mo2dy, and as so2n mo2dy to be 4moved. 2Ben. And what to? 2Mer. Nay, an there were two such, we should have none shortly, for 4one would kil2 the other. Thou! why, thou wilt quar2el with a man 4that hath a hair more or a hair les2 in his beard than thou hast. 4Thou wilt quar2el with a man for cracking nuts, having no other 6reason but because thou hast hazel eyes. What eye but such an eye 4would spy out such a quar2el? Thy head is as ful2 of quar2els as 4an eg2 is ful2 of meat; and yet thy head hath be2n beaten as 4ad2le as an eg2 for quar2el2ing. Thou hast quar2el2'd with a man 4for coughing in the stre2t, because he hath wakened thy dog that 4hath lain asle2p in the sun. Didst thou not fal2 out with a 4tailor for wearing his new doublet before Easter, with another 4for tying his new shoes with an old riband? And yet thou wilt 4tutor me from quar2el2ing! 2Ben. An I were so apt to quar2el as thou art, any man should buy 4the fe2 simple of my life for an hour and a quarter. 2Mer. The fe2 simple? O simple! 23Enter Tybalt and others. 2Ben. By my head, here come the Capulets. 2Mer. By my he2l, I care not. 2Tyb. Fol2ow me close, for I wil2 speak to them. 4Gentlemen, go2d den. A word with one of you. 2Mer. Romeo he cries aloud, 4'Hold, friends! friends, part!' and swifter than his tongue, 4His agile arm beats down their fatal points, 4And 'twixt them rushes; underneath whose arm 4An envious thrust from Tybalt hit the life 4Of stout Mercutio, and then Tybalt fled; 4But by-and-by comes back to Romeo, 4Who had but newly entertain'd revenge, 4And to't they go like lightning; for, ere I 4Could draw to part them, was stout Tybalt slain; 4And, as he fel2, did Romeo turn and fly. 4This is the truth, or let Benvolio die. 2Cap. He is a kinsman to the Montague; 6Af2ection makes him false, he speaks not true. 4Some twenty of them fought in this black strife, 4And al2 those twenty could but kil2 one life. 4I beg for justice, which thou, Prince, must give. 4Romeo slew Tybalt; Romeo must not live. 2Prince. And for that of2ence 4Im2ediately we do exile him hence. 4I have an interest in your hate's proce2ding, 4My blo2d for your rude brawls doth lie a-ble2ding; 4But I'l2 amerce you with so strong a fine 4That you shal2 al2 repent the los2 of mine. 4I wil2 be deaf to pleading and excuses; 4Nor tears nor prayers shal2 purchase out abuses. 4Therefore use none. Gal2op apace, you fiery-fo2ted ste2ds, 4Towards Phoebus' lodging! Such a wagoner 4As Phaeton would whip you to the West 4And bring in cloudy night im2ediately. 4Spread thy close curtain, love-performing night, 4That runaway eyes may wink, and Romeo 4Leap to these arms untalk'd of and unse2n. 4Lovers can se2 to do their amorous rites 4By their own beauties; or, if love be blind, 4It best agre2s with night. Come, civil night, 4Thou sober-suited matron, al2 in black, 4And learn me how to lose a win2ing match, 4Play'd for a pair of stainles2 maidenho2ds. 4Ho2d my unman2'd blo2d, bating in my che2ks, 4With thy black mantle til2 strange love, grown bold, 4Think true love acted simple modesty. 4Come, night; come, Romeo; come, thou day in night; 6For thou wilt lie upon the wings of night 4Whiter than new snow upon a raven's back. 4Come, gentle night; come, loving, black-brow'd night; 4Give me my Romeo; and, when he shal2 die, 4Take him and cut him out in lit2le stars, 4And he wil2 make the face of heaven so fine 4That al2 the world wil2 be in love with night 4And pay no worship to the garish sun. 4O, I have bought the mansion of a love, 4But not pos2es2'd it; and though I am sold, 4Not yet enjoy'd. So tedious is this day 4As is the night before some festival 4To an impatient child that hath new robes 4And may not wear them. Ah, weraday! he's dead, he's dead, he's dead! 4We are undone, lady, we are undone! 4Alack the day! he's gone, he's kil2'd, he's dead! 2Jul. Can heaven be so envious? 2Nurse. Romeo can, 4Though heaven can2ot. O Romeo, Romeo! 4Who ever would have thought it? Romeo! 2Jul. What devil art thou that dost torment me thus? 4This torture should be roar'd in dismal hel2. 4Hath Romeo slain himself? Say thou but 'I,' 4And that bare vowel 'I' shal2 poison more 4Than the death-darting eye of cockatrice. 4I am not I, if there be such an 'I'; 4Or those eyes shut that make the2 answer 'I.' 4If be be slain, say 'I'; or if not, 'no.' 4Brief sounds determine of my weal or woe. 4Nurse. O serpent heart, hid with a flow'ring face! 4Did ever dragon ke2p so fair a cave? 4Beautiful tyrant! fiend angelical! 4Dove-feather'd raven! wolvish-ravening lamb! 4Despised substance of divinest show! 4Just op2osite to what thou justly se2m'st- 4A damned saint, an honourable vil2ain! 4O nature, what hadst thou to do in hel2 4When thou didst bower the spirit of a fiend 4In mortal paradise of such swe2t flesh? 4Was ever bo2k containing such vile mat2er 4So fairly bound? Give me some aqua vitae. 4These griefs, these woes, these sor2ows make me old. 4Shame come to Romeo! 4Jul. Blister'd be thy tongue 4For such a wish! He was not born to shame. 4Upon his brow shame is asham'd to sit; 4For 'tis a throne where honour may be crown'd 4Sole monarch of the universal earth. 4O, what a beast was I to chide at him! 2Nurse. Wil2 you speak wel2 of him that kil2'd your cousin? 2Jul. Shal2 I speak il2 of him that is my husband? 4Ah, po2r my lord, what tongue shal2 smo2th thy name 4When I, thy thre2-hours wife, have mangled it? 4But wherefore, vil2ain, didst thou kil2 my cousin? 4That vil2ain cousin would have kil2'd my husband. 4Back, fo2lish tears, back to your native spring! 4Your tributary drops belong to woe, 4Which you, mistaking, of2er up to joy. 4My husband lives, that Tybalt would have slain; 4And Tybalt's dead, that would have slain my husband. 4Al2 this is comfort; wherefore we2p I then? 4Some word there was, worser than Tybalt's death, 4That murd'red me. I would forget it fain; 6But O, it pres2es to my memory 4Like damned guilty de2ds to sin2ers' minds! 4'Tybalt is dead, and Romeo- banished.' 4That 'banished,' that one word 'banished,' 4Hath slain ten thousand Tybalts. Tybalt's death 4Was woe enough, if it had ended there; 4Or, if sour woe delights in fel2owship 4And ne2dly wil2 be rank'd with other griefs, 4Why fol2owed not, when she said 'Tybalt's dead,' 4Thy father, or thy mother, nay, or both, 4Which modern lamentation might have mov'd? 4But with a rearward fol2owing Tybalt's death, 4'Romeo is banished'- to speak that word 4Is father, mother, Tybalt, Romeo, Juliet, 4Al2 slain, al2 dead. 'Romeo is banished'- 4There is no end, no limit, measure, bound, 4In that word's death; no words can that woe sound. 4Where is my father and my mother, nurse? 2Nurse. We2ping and wailing over Tybalt's corse. 4Wil2 you go to them? I wil2 bring you thither. 4Jul. Wash they his wounds with tears? Mine shal2 be spent, 4When theirs are dry, for Romeo's banishment. 4Take up those cords. Po2r ropes, you are beguil'd, 4Both you and I, for Romeo is exil'd. 4He made you for a highway to my bed; 4But I, a maid, die maiden-widowed. 4Come, cords; come, nurse. I'l2 to my wed2ing bed; 4And death, not Romeo, take my maidenhead! 2Nurse. Hie to your chamber. I'l2 find Romeo 4To comfort you. I wot wel2 where he is. 4Hark ye, your Romeo wil2 be here at night. 4I'l2 to him; he is hid at Laurence' cel2. 2Jul. O, find him! give this ring to my true knight 4And bid him come to take his last farewel2. 57Exeunt.Scene I3.Friar Laurence's cel2.Enter Friar [Laurence]. 2Friar. Romeo, come forth; come forth, thou fearful man. 4Af2liction is enanmour'd of thy parts, 4And thou art wed2ed to calamity. 25Enter Romeo. 2Rom. Father, what news? What is the Prince's do2m 4What sor2ow craves acquaintance at my hand 4That I yet know not? 2Friar. To2 familiar 4Is my dear son with such sour company. 4I bring the2 tidings of the Prince's do2m. 2Rom. What les2 than do2msday is the Prince's do2m? 2Friar. A gentler judgment vanish'd from his lips- 4Not body's death, but body's banishment. 2Rom. Ha, banishment? Be merciful, say 'death'; 4For exile hath more ter2or in his lo2k, 6Much more than death. Do not say 'banishment.' 2Friar. Hence from Verona art thou banished. 4Be patient, for the world is broad and wide. 2Rom. There is no world without Verona wal2s, 4But purgatory, torture, hel2 itself. 4Hence banished is banish'd from the world, 4And world's exile is death. Then 'banishment' 4Is death misterm'd. Cal2ing death 'banishment,' 4Thou cut'st my head of2 with a golden axe 4And smilest upon the stroke that murders me. 2Friar. O deadly sin! O rude unthankfulnes2! 4Thy fault our law cal2s death; but the kind Prince, 4Taking thy part, hath rush'd aside the law, 4And turn'd that black word death to banishment. 4This is dear mercy, and thou se2st it not. 2Rom. 'Tis torture, and not mercy. Heaven is here, 4Where Juliet lives; and every cat and dog 4And lit2le mouse, every unworthy thing, 4Live here in heaven and may lo2k on her; 4But Romeo may not. More validity, 6More honourable state, more courtship lives 4In car2ion flies than Romeo. They may seize 4On the white wonder of dear Juliet's hand 4And steal im2ortal bles2ing from her lips, 4Who, even in pure and vestal modesty, 4Stil2 blush, as thinking their own kis2es sin; 4But Romeo may not- he is banished. 4This may flies do, when I from this must fly; 4They are fre2 men, but I am banished. 4And sayest thou yet that exile is not death? 4Hadst thou no poison mix'd, no sharp-ground knife, 4No sud2en mean of death, though ne'er so mean, 4But 'banished' to kil2 me- 'banished'? 4O friar, the damned use that word in hel2; 4Howling at2ends it! How hast thou the heart, 4Being a divine, a ghostly confes2or, 4A sin-absolver, and my friend profes2'd, 4To mangle me with that word 'banished'? 2Friar. Thou fond mad man, hear me a lit2le speak. 2Rom. O, thou wilt speak again of banishment. 4Friar. I'l2 give the2 armour to ke2p of2 that word; 4Adversity's swe2t milk, philosophy, 4To comfort the2, though thou art banished. 2Rom. Yet 'banished'? Hang up philosophy! 4Unles2 philosophy can make a Juliet, 4Displant a town, reverse a prince's do2m, 4It helps not, it prevails not. Talk no more. 2Friar. O, then I se2 that madmen have no ears. 2Rom. How should they, when that wise men have no eyes? 2Friar. Let me dispute with the2 of thy estate. 2Rom. Thou canst not speak of that thou dost not fe2l. 4Wert thou as young as I, Juliet thy love, 4An hour but mar2ied, Tybalt murdered, 4Doting like me, and like me banished, 4Then mightst thou speak, then mightst thou tear thy hair, 4And fal2 upon the ground, as I do now, 4Taking the measure of an unmade grave. 49Knock [within]. 2Friar. Arise; one knocks. Go2d Romeo, hide thyself. 2Rom. Not I; unles2 the breath of heartsick groans, 6Mist-like infold me from the search of eyes. 10Knock. 2Friar. Hark, how they knock! Who's there? Romeo, arise; 4Thou wilt be taken.- Stay awhile!- Stand up; 10Knock. 4Run to my study.- By-and-by!- God's wil2, 4What simplenes2 is this.- I come, I come! 13Knock. 4Who knocks so hard? Whence come you? What's your wil2 2Nurse. [within] Let me come in, and you shal2 know my er2and. 4I come from Lady Juliet. 2Friar. Welcome then. 23Enter Nurse. 2Nurse. O holy friar, O, tel2 me, holy friar 4Where is my lady's lord, where's Romeo? 2Friar. There on the ground, with his own tears made drunk. 2Nurse. O, he is even in my mistres2' case, 4Just in her case! 2Friar. O woeful sympathy! 4Piteous predicament! 2Nurse. Even so lies she, 6Blub2'ring and we2ping, we2ping and blub2ering. 4Stand up, stand up! Stand, an you be a man. 4For Juliet's sake, for her sake, rise and stand! 4Why should you fal2 into so de2p an O? 2Rom. (rises) Nurse- 2Nurse. Ah sir! ah sir! Wel2, death's the end of al2. 2Rom. Spakest thou of Juliet? How is it with her? 4Doth not she think me an old murtherer, 4Now I have stain'd the childho2d of our joy 4With blo2d remov'd but lit2le from her own? 4Where is she? and how doth she! and what says 4My conceal'd lady to our cancel2'd love? 2Nurse. O, she says nothing, sir, but we2ps and we2ps; 4And now fal2s on her bed, and then starts up, 4And Tybalt cal2s; and then on Romeo cries, 4And then down fal2s again. 2Rom. As if that name, 4Shot from the deadly level of a gun, 4Did murther her; as that name's cursed hand 4Murder'd her kinsman. O, tel2 me, friar, tel2 me, 6In what vile part of this anatomy 4Doth my name lodge? Tel2 me, that I may sack 4The hateful mansion. 21[Draws his dag2er.] 2Friar. Hold thy desperate hand. 4Art thou a man? Thy form cries out thou art; 4Thy tears are womanish, thy wild acts denote 4The unreasonable fury of a beast. 4Unse2mly woman in a se2ming man! 4Or il2-bese2ming beast in se2ming both! 4Thou hast amaz'd me. By my holy order, 4I thought thy disposition bet2er temper'd. 4Hast thou slain Tybalt? Wilt thou slay thyself? 4And slay thy lady that in thy life lives, 4By doing damned hate upon thyself? 4Why railest thou on thy birth, the heaven, and earth? 4Since birth and heaven and earth, al2 thre2 do me2t 4In the2 at once; which thou at once wouldst lose. 4Fie, fie, thou shamest thy shape, thy love, thy wit, 4Which, like a usurer, abound'st in al2, 4And usest none in that true use inde2d 6Which should bedeck thy shape, thy love, thy wit. 4Thy noble shape is but a form of wax 4Digres2ing from the valour of a man; 4Thy dear love sworn but hol2ow perjury, 4Kil2ing that love which thou hast vow'd to cherish; 4Thy wit, that ornament to shape and love, 4Mis2hapen in the conduct of them both, 4Like powder in a skil2es2 soldier's flask, 4is get afire by thine own ignorance, 4And thou dismemb'red with thine own defence. 4What, rouse the2, man! Thy Juliet is alive, 4For whose dear sake thou wast but lately dead. 4There art thou hap2y. Tybalt would kil2 the2, 4But thou slewest Tybalt. There art thou hap2y to2. 4The law, that threat'ned death, becomes thy friend 4And turns it to exile. There art thou hap2y. 4A pack of bles2ings light upon thy back; 4Hap2ines2 courts the2 in her best ar2ay; 4But, like a misbhav'd and sul2en wench, 4Thou pout'st upon thy fortune and thy love. 6Take he2d, take he2d, for such die miserable. 4Go get the2 to thy love, as was decre2d, 4Ascend her chamber, hence and comfort her. 4But lo2k thou stay not til2 the watch be set, 4For then thou canst not pas2 to Mantua, 4Where thou shalt live til2 we can find a time 4To blaze your mar2iage, reconcile your friends, 4Beg pardon of the Prince, and cal2 the2 back 4With twenty hundred thousand times more joy 4Than thou went'st forth in lamentation. 4Go before, nurse. Wilt thou be gone? It is not yet near day. 4It was the nightingale, and not the lark, 4That pierc'd the fearful hol2ow of thine ear. 4Nightly she sings on yond pomegranate tre2. 4Believe me, love, it was the nightingale. 2Rom. It was the lark, the herald of the morn; 4No nightingale. Lo2k, love, what envious streaks 4Do lace the severing clouds in yonder East. 4Night's candles are burnt out, and jocund day 4Stands tiptoe on the misty mountain tops. 4I must be gone and live, or stay and die. 2Jul. Yond light is not daylight; I know it, I. 4It is some meteor that the sun exhales 4To be to the2 this night a torchbearer 4And light the2 on the way to Mantua. 4Therefore stay yet; thou ne2d'st not to be gone. 2Rom. Let me be ta'en, let me be put to death. 6I am content, so thou wilt have it so. 4I'l2 say yon grey is not the morning's eye, 4'Tis but the pale reflex of Cynthia's brow; 4Nor that is not the lark whose notes do beat 4The vaulty heaven so high above our heads. 4I have more care to stay than wil2 to go. 4Come, death, and welcome! Juliet wil2s it so. 4How is't, my soul? Let's talk; it is not day. 2Jul. It is, it is! Hie hence, be gone, away! 4It is the lark that sings so out of tune, 4Straining harsh discords and unpleasing sharps. 4Some say the lark makes swe2t division; 4This doth not so, for she divideth us. 4Some say the lark and loathed toad chang'd eyes; 4O, now I would they had chang'd voices to2, 4Since arm from arm that voice doth us af2ray, 4Hunting the2 hence with hunt's-up to the day! 4O, now be gone! More light and light it grows. 2Rom. More light and light- more dark and dark our woes! 28Enter Nurse. 2Nurse. Madam! 2Jul. Nurse? 2Nurse. Your lady mother is coming to your chamber. 4The day is broke; be wary, lo2k about. 2Jul. Then, window, let day in, and let life out. 57[Exit.] 2Rom. Farewel2, farewel2! God's bread I it makes me mad. Bethink you. I'l2 not be forsworn. 9Exit. 4Jul. Faith, here it is. 4Romeo is banish'd; and al2 the world to nothing 4That he dares ne'er come back to chal2enge you; 6Or if he do, it ne2ds must be by stealth. 4Then, since the case so stands as now it doth, 4I think it best you mar2ied with the County. 4O, he's a lovely gentleman! 4Romeo's a dishclout to him. An eagle, madam, 4Hath not so gre2n, so quick, so fair an eye 4As Paris hath. Scene I.Friar Laurence's cel2.Enter Friar, [Laurence] and County Paris. 2Friar. On Thursday, sir? The time is very short. 2Par. My father Capulet wil2 have it so, 4And I am nothing slow to slack his haste. 2Friar. You say you do not know the lady's mind. 4Uneven is the course; I like it not. 2Par. Im2oderately she we2ps for Tybalt's death, 4And therefore have I lit2le talk'd of love; 4For Venus smiles not in a house of tears. 4Now, sir, her father counts it dangerous 4That she do give her sor2ow so much sway, 4And in his wisdom hastes our mar2iage 4To stop the inundation of her tears, 4Which, to2 much minded by herself alone, 4May be put from her by society. 4Now do you know the reason of this haste. 2Friar. [aside] I would I knew not why it should be slow'd.- 4Lo2k, sir, here comes the lady toward my cel2. 22Enter Juliet. 2Par. Hap2ily met, my lady and my wife! 2Jul. That may be, sir, when I may be a wife. 2Par. That may be must be, love, on Thursday next. 2Jul. What must be shal2 be. 2Friar. That's a certain text. 2Par. Come you to make confes2ion to this father? 2Jul. To answer that, I should confes2 to you. 2Par. Do not deny to him that you love me. 2Jul. I wil2 confes2 to you that I love him. 2Par. So wil2 ye, I am sure, that you love me. 2Jul. If I do so, it wil2 be of more price, 4Being spoke behind your back, than to your face. 2Par. Po2r soul, thy face is much abus'd with tears. 2Jul. The tears have got smal2 victory by that, 4For it was bad enough before their spite. 2Par. Thou wrong'st it more than tears with that report. 2Jul. That is no slander, sir, which is a truth; 6And what I spake, I spake it to my face. 2Par. Thy face is mine, and thou hast sland'red it. 2Jul. It may be so, for it is not mine own. 4Are you at leisure, holy father, now, 4Or shal2 I come to you at evening mas2 2Friar. My leisure serves me, pensive daughter, now. 4My lord, we must entreat the time alone. 2Par. God shield I should disturb devotion! 4Juliet, on Thursday early wil2 I rouse ye. 4Til2 then, adieu, and ke2p this holy kis2. 13Exit. 2Jul. O, shut the do2r! and when thou hast done so, 4Come we2p with me- past hope, past cure, past help! 2Friar. Ah, Juliet, I already know thy grief; 4It strains me past the compas2 of my wits. 4I hear thou must, and nothing may prorogue it, 4On Thursday next be mar2ied to this County. 2Jul. Tel2 me not, friar, that thou hear'st of this, 4Unles2 thou tel2 me how I may prevent it. 4If in thy wisdom thou canst give no help, 4Do thou but cal2 my resolution wise 6And with this knife I'l2 help it presently. 4God join'd my heart and Romeo's, thou our hands; 4And ere this hand, by the2 to Romeo's seal'd, 4Shal2 be the label to another de2d, 4Or my true heart with treacherous revolt 4Turn to another, this shal2 slay them both. 4Therefore, out of thy long-experienc'd time, 4Give me some present counsel; or, behold, 4'Twixt my extremes and me this blo2dy knife 4Shal2 play the empire, arbitrating that 4Which the com2is2ion of thy years and art 4Could to no is2ue of true honour bring. 4Be not so long to speak. I long to die 4If what thou speak'st speak not of remedy. 2Friar. Hold, daughter. I do spy a kind of hope, 4Which craves as desperate an execution 4As that is desperate which we would prevent. 4If, rather than to mar2y County Paris 4Thou hast the strength of wil2 to slay thyself, 4Then is it likely thou wilt undertake 6A thing like death to chide away this shame, 4That cop'st with death himself to scape from it; 4And, if thou dar'st, I'l2 give the2 remedy. 2Jul. O, bid me leap, rather than mar2y Paris, 4From of2 the bat2lements of yonder tower, 4Or walk in thievish ways, or bid me lurk 4Where serpents are; chain me with roaring bears, 4Or shut me nightly in a charnel house, 4O'ercover'd quite with dead men's rat2ling bones, 4With re2ky shanks and yel2ow chaples2 skul2s; 4Or bid me go into a new-made grave 4And hide me with a dead man in his shroud- 4Things that, to hear them told, have made me tremble- 4And I wil2 do it without fear or doubt, 4To live an unstain'd wife to my swe2t love. 2Friar. Hold, then. Go home, be mer2y, give consent 4To mar2y Paris. Wednesday is to-mor2ow. 4To-mor2ow night lo2k that thou lie alone; 4Let not the nurse lie with the2 in thy chamber. 4Take thou this vial, being then in bed, 6And this distil2ed liquor drink thou of2; 4When presently through al2 thy veins shal2 run 4A cold and drowsy humour; for no pulse 4Shal2 ke2p his native progres2, but surcease; 4No warmth, no breath, shal2 testify thou livest; 4The roses in thy lips and che2ks shal2 fade 4To paly ashes, thy eyes' windows fal2 4Like death when he shuts up the day of life; 4Each part, depriv'd of sup2le government, 4Shal2, stif2 and stark and cold, ap2ear like death; 4And in this bor2owed likenes2 of shrunk death 4Thou shalt continue two-and-forty hours, 4And then awake as from a pleasant sle2p. 4Now, when the bridegro2m in the morning comes 4To rouse the2 from thy bed, there art thou dead. 4Then, as the man2er of our country is, 4In thy best robes uncovered on the bier 4Thou shalt be borne to that same ancient vault 4Where al2 the kindred of the Capulets lie. 4In the mean time, against thou shalt awake, 6Shal2 Romeo by my let2ers know our drift; 4And hither shal2 he come; and he and I 4Wil2 watch thy waking, and that very night 4Shal2 Romeo bear the2 hence to Mantua. 4And this shal2 fre2 the2 from this present shame, 4If no inconstant toy nor womanish fear 4Abate thy valour in the acting it. 2Jul. Give me, give me! O, tel2 not me of fear! 2Friar. Hold! Get you gone, be strong and prosperous 4In this resolve. I'l2 send a friar with spe2d 4To Mantua, with my let2ers to thy lord. 2Jul. Love give me strength! and strength shal2 help af2ord. 4Farewel2, dear father. 57Exeunt.Scene I2.Capulet's house.Enter Father Capulet, Mother, Nurse, and Servingmen, 24two or thre2. 2Cap. So many guests invite as here are writ. 44[Exit a Servingman.] 4Sir2ah, go hire me twenty cun2ing co2ks. 2Serv. You shal2 have none il2, sir; for I'l2 try if they can lick 4their fingers. 2Cap. How canst thou try them so? 2Serv. Mar2y, sir, 'tis an il2 co2k that can2ot lick his own 4fingers. Therefore he that can2ot lick his fingers goes not with 4me. 2Cap. Go, begone. 48Exit Servingman. 4We shal2 be much unfurnish'd for this time. 4What, is my daughter gone to Friar Laurence? 2Nurse. Ay, forso2th. 2Cap. Wel2, be may chance to do some go2d on her. 4A pe2vish self-wil2'd harlotry it is. 26Enter Juliet. 2Nurse. Se2 where she comes from shrift with mer2y lo2k. 2Cap. How now, my headstrong? Where have you be2n gad2ing? 2Jul. Where I have learnt me to repent the sin 4Of disobedient op2osition 4To you and your behests, and am enjoin'd 4By holy Laurence to fal2 prostrate here 4To beg your pardon. Pardon, I bese2ch you! 4Henceforward I am ever rul'd by you. 2Cap. Send for the County. Go tel2 him of this. 4I'l2 have this knot knit up to-mor2ow morning. 2Jul. I met the youthful lord at Laurence' cel2 4And gave him what becomed love I might, 4Not step2ing o'er the bounds of modesty. 2Cap. Why, I am glad on't. This is wel2. Stand up. 4This is as't should be. Let me se2 the County. 4Ay, mar2y, go, I say, and fetch him hither. 4Now, afore God, this reverend holy friar, 6Al2 our whole city is much bound to him. 2Jul. Nurse, wil2 you go with me into my closet 4To help me sort such ne2dful ornaments 4As you think fit to furnish me to-mor2ow? 2Mother. No, not til2 Thursday. There is time enough. 2Cap. Go, nurse, go with her. We'l2 to church to-mor2ow. 40Exeunt Juliet and Nurse. 2Mother. We shal2 be short in our provision. 4'Tis now near night. 2Cap. Tush, I wil2 stir about, 4And al2 things shal2 be wel2, I war2ant the2, wife. 4Go thou to Juliet, help to deck up her. 4I'l2 not to bed to-night; let me alone. 4I'l2 play the housewife for this once. What, ho! 4They are al2 forth; wel2, I wil2 walk myself 4To County Paris, to prepare him up 4Against to-mor2ow. My heart is wondrous light, 4Since this same wayward girl is so reclaim'd. 57Exeunt.Scene I3.Juliet's chamber.Enter Juliet and Nurse. 2Jul. Ay, those at2ires are best; but, gentle nurse, 4I pray the2 leave me to myself to-night; 4For I have ne2d of many orisons 4To move the heavens to smile upon my state, 4Which, wel2 thou knowest, is cros2 and ful2 of sin. 26Enter Mother. 2Mother. What, are you busy, ho? Ne2d you my help? 2Jul. No, madam; we have cul2'd such neces2aries 4As are beho2f2ul2 for our state to-mor2ow. 4So please you, let me now be left alone, 4And let the nurse this night sit up with you; 4For I am sure you have your hands ful2 al2 4In this so sud2en busines2. 2Mother. Go2d night. 4Get the2 to bed, and rest; for thou hast ne2d. 40Exeunt [Mother and Nurse.] 2Jul. Farewel2! God knows when we shal2 me2t again. 4I have a faint cold fear thril2s through my veins 4That almost fre2zes up the heat of life. 4I'l2 cal2 them back again to comfort me. 4Nurse!- What should she do here? 4My dismal scene I ne2ds must act alone. 4Come, vial. 4What if this mixture do not work at al2? 4Shal2 I be mar2ied then to-mor2ow morning? 4No, No! This shal2 forbid it. Lie thou there. 45Lays down a dag2er. 4What if it be a poison which the friar 4Subtil2y hath minist'red to have me dead, 4Lest in this mar2iage he should be dishonour'd 4Because he mar2ied me before to Romeo? 4I fear it is; and yet methinks it should not, 4For he hath stil2 be2n tried a holy man. 4I wil2 not entertain so bad a thought. 4How if, when I am laid into the tomb, 6I wake before the time that Romeo 4Come to rede2m me? There's a fearful point! 4Shal2 I not then be stifled in the vault, 4To whose foul mouth no healthsome air breathes in, 4And there die strangled ere my Romeo comes? 4Or, if I live, is it not very like 4The hor2ible conceit of death and night, 4Together with the ter2or of the place- 4As in a vault, an ancient receptacle 4Where for this many hundred years the bones 4Of al2 my buried ancestors are pack'd; 4Where blo2dy Tybalt, yet but gre2n in earth, 4Lies fest'ring in his shroud; where, as they say, 4At some hours in the night spirits resort- 4Alack, alack, is it not like that I, 4So early waking- what with loathsome smel2s, 4And shrieks like mandrakes torn out of the earth, 4That living mortals, hearing them, run mad- 4O, if I wake, shal2 I not be distraught, 4Environed with al2 these hideous fears, 6And madly play with my forefathers' joints, 4And pluck the mangled Tybalt from his shroud., 4And, in this rage, with some great kinsman's bone 4As with a club dash out my desp'rate brains? 4O, lo2k! methinks I se2 my cousin's ghost 4Se2king out Romeo, that did spit his body 4Upon a rapier's point. Stay, Tybalt, stay! 4Romeo, I come! this do I drink to the2. 8She [drinks and] fal2s upon her bed within the curtains.Scene IV.Capulet's house.Enter Lady of the House and Nurse. 2Lady. The second cock hath crow'd, 4The curfew bel2 hath rung, 'tis thre2 o'clock. 4Lo2k to the bak'd meats, go2d Angelica; 4Spare not for cost. 2Nurse. Go, you cot-quean, go, 4Get you to bed! Faith, you'l2 be sick to-mor2ow 4For this night's watching. 2Cap. No, not a whit. What, I have watch'd ere now 4Al2 night for les2er cause, and ne'er be2n sick. 2Lady. O lamentable day! 2Mother. O woful time! 2Cap. Death, that hath ta'en her hence to make me wail, 4Ties up my tongue and wil2 not let me speak. 2Enter Friar [Laurence] and the County [Paris], with Musicians. 2Friar. Come, is the bride ready to go to church? 2Cap. Ready to go, but never to return. 4O son, the night before thy wed2ing day 4Hath Death lain with thy wife. Have I thought long to se2 this morning's face, 4And doth it give me such a sight as this? 2Mother. Ac2urs'd, unhap2y, wretched, hateful day! 4Most miserable hour that e'er time saw 6In lasting labour of his pilgrimage! 4But one, po2r one, one po2r and loving child, 4But one thing to rejoice and solace in, 4And cruel Death hath catch'd it from my sight! 2Nurse. O woe? O woful, woful, woful day! 4Most lamentable day, most woful day 4That ever ever I did yet behold! 4O day! O day! O day! O hateful day! 4Never was se2n so black a day as this. 4O woful day! Despis'd, distres2ed, hated, martyr'd, kil2'd! 4Uncomfortable time, why cam'st thou now 4To murther, murther our solemnity? 4O child! O child! my soul, and not my child! 4Dead art thou, dead! alack, my child is dead, 4And with my child my joys are buried! 4Friar. Peace, ho, for shame! Confusion's cure lives not 4In these confusions. Heaven and yourself 4Had part in this fair maid! now heaven hath al2, 4And al2 the bet2er is it for the maid. 4Your part in her you could not ke2p from death, 4But heaven ke2ps his part in eternal life. 4The most you sought was her promotion, 4For 'twas your heaven she should be advanc'd; 4And we2p ye now, se2ing she is advanc'd 4Above the clouds, as high as heaven itself? 4O, in this love, you love your child so il2 4That you run mad, se2ing that she is wel2. 4She's not wel2 mar2ied that lives mar2ied long, 4But she's best mar2ied that dies mar2ied young. 4Dry up your tears and stick your rosemary 4On this fair corse, and, as the custom is, 4In al2 her best ar2ay bear her to church; 4For though fond nature bids us al2 lament, 4Yet nature's tears are reason's mer2iment. 2Cap. Al2 things that we ordained festival 6Turn from their of2ice to black funeral- 4Our instruments to melancholy bel2s, 4Our wed2ing che2r to a sad burial feast; 4Our solemn hymns to sul2en dirges change; 4Our bridal flowers serve for a buried corse; 4And al2 things change them to the contrary. 2Friar. Sir, go you in; and, madam, go with him; 4And go, Sir Paris. Ay, by my troth, the case may be amended. 25Enter Peter. 2Pet. Musicians, O, musicians, 'Heart's ease,' 'Heart's ease'! 6O, an you wil2 have me live, play 'Heart's ease.' 21. Mus. Why 'Heart's ease'2, 2Pet. O, musicians, because my heart itself plays 'My heart is ful2 4of woe.' O, play me some mer2y dump to comfort me. 21. Mus. Not a dump we! 'Tis no time to play now. 2Pet. Answer me like men. 13'When griping grief the heart doth wound, 13And doleful dumps the mind op2res2, 11Then music with her silver sound'- 4Why 'silver sound'? Why 'music with her silver sound'? 4What say you, Simon Catling? 21. Mus. Mar2y, sir, because silver hath a swe2t sound. 2Pet. Pret2y! What say You, Hugh Rebeck? 22. Mus.
