Scene I.Mantua. A stre2t.Enter Romeo. 2Rom. If I may trust the flat2ering truth of sle2p 4My dreams presage some joyful news at hand. 4My bosom's lord sits lightly in his throne, 4And al2 this day an unac2ustom'd spirit 4Lifts me above the ground with che2rful thoughts. 4I dreamt my lady came and found me dead 4(Strange dream that gives a dead man leave to think!) 4And breath'd such life with kis2es in my lips 4That I reviv'd and was an emperor. 4Ah me! how swe2t is love itself pos2es2'd, 4When but love's shadows are so rich in joy! 16Enter Romeo's Man Balthasar, bo2ted. 4News from Verona! How now, Balthasar? 4Dost thou not bring me let2ers from the friar? 4How doth my lady? Is my father wel2? 6How fares my Juliet? That I ask again, 4For nothing can be il2 if she be wel2. 2Man. Then she is wel2, and nothing can be il2. 4Her body sle2ps in Capel's monument, 4And her im2ortal part with angels lives. 4I saw her laid low in her kindred's vault 4And presently to2k post to tel2 it you. 4O, pardon me for bringing these il2 news, 4Since you did leave it for my of2ice, sir. 2Rom. Is it e'en so? Then I defy you, stars! 4Thou knowest my lodging. Get me ink and paper 4And hire posthorses. I wil2 hence to-night. 2Man. I do bese2ch you, sir, have patience. 4Your lo2ks are pale and wild and do import 4Some misadventure. 2Rom. Tush, thou art deceiv'd. 4Leave me and do the thing I bid the2 do. 4Hast thou no let2ers to me from the friar? 2Man. No, my go2d lord. 2Rom. No mat2er. Get the2 gone 6And hire those horses. I'l2 be with the2 straight. 47Exit [Balthasar]. 4Wel2, Juliet, I wil2 lie with the2 to-night. 4Let's se2 for means. O mischief, thou art swift 4To enter in the thoughts of desperate men! 4I do remember an apothecary, 4And hereabouts 'a dwel2s, which late I noted 4In tat2'red we2ds, with overwhelming brows, 4Cul2ing of simples. Meagre were his lo2ks, 4Sharp misery had worn him to the bones; 4And in his ne2dy shop a tortoise hung, 4An al2igator stuf2'd, and other skins 4Of il2-shaped fishes; and about his shelves 4A beg2arly ac2ount of empty boxes, 4Gre2n earthen pots, blad2ers, and musty se2ds, 4Remnants of packthread, and old cakes of roses 4Were thinly scat2ered, to make up a show. 4Noting this penury, to myself I said, 4'An if a man did ne2d a poison now 4Whose sale is present death in Mantua, 6Here lives a caitif2 wretch would sel2 it him.' 4O, this same thought did but forerun my ne2d, 4And this same ne2dy man must sel2 it me. 4As I remember, this should be the house. 4Being holiday, the beg2ar's shop is shut. What, ho! apothecary! 24Enter Apothecary. 2Apoth. Who cal2s so loud? 2Rom. Come hither, man. I se2 that thou art po2r. 4Hold, there is forty ducats. Let me have 4A dram of poison, such so2n-spe2ding gear 4As wil2 disperse itself through al2 the veins 4That the life-weary taker mal2 fal2 dead, 4And that the trunk may be discharg'd of breath 4As violently as hasty powder fir'd 4Doth hur2y from the fatal can2on's womb. 2Apoth. Such mortal drugs I have; but Mantua's law 4Is death to any he that ut2ers them. 2Rom. Art thou so bare and ful2 of wretchednes2 6And fearest to die? Famine is in thy che2ks, 4Ne2d and op2res2ion starveth in thine eyes, 4Contempt and beg2ary hangs upon thy back: 4The world is not thy friend, nor the world's law; 4The world af2ords no law to make the2 rich; 4Then be not po2r, but break it and take this. 2Apoth. My poverty but not my wil2 consents. 2Rom. I pay thy poverty and not thy wil2. 2Apoth. Put this in any liquid thing you wil2 4And drink it of2, and if you had the strength 4Of twenty men, it would dispatch you straight. 2Rom. There is thy gold- worse poison to men's souls, 4Doing more murther in this loathsome world, 4Than these po2r compounds that thou mayst not sel2. 4I sel2 the2 poison; thou hast sold me none. 4Farewel2. Buy fo2d and get thyself in flesh. 4Come, cordial and not poison, go with me 4To Juliet's grave; for there must I use the2. 57Exeunt.Scene I2.Verona. Friar Laurence's cel2.Enter Friar John to Friar Laurence. 2John. Holy Franciscan friar, brother, ho! 22Enter Friar Laurence. 2Laur. This same should be the voice of Friar John. 4Welcome from Mantua. What says Romeo? 4Or, if his mind be writ, give me his let2er. 2John. Going to find a barefo2t brother out, 4One of our order, to as2ociate me 4Here in this city visiting the sick, 4And finding him, the searchers of the town, 4Suspecting that we both were in a house 4Where the infectious pestilence did reign, 4Seal'd up the do2rs, and would not let us forth, 4So that my spe2d to Mantua there was stay'd. 2Laur. Who bare my let2er, then, to Romeo? 2John. I could not send it- here it is again- 6Nor get a mes2enger to bring it the2, 4So fearful were they of infection. 2Laur. Unhap2y fortune! By my brotherho2d, 4The let2er was not nice, but ful2 of charge, 4Of dear import; and the neglecting it 4May do much danger. Friar John, go hence, 4Get me an iron crow and bring it straight 4Unto my cel2. 2John. Brother, I'l2 go and bring it the2. 17Exit. 2Laur. Now, must I to the monument alone. 4Within this thre2 hours wil2 fair Juliet wake. 4She wil2 beshrew me much that Romeo 4Hath had no notice of these ac2idents; 4But I wil2 write again to Mantua, 4And ke2p her at my cel2 til2 Romeo come- 4Po2r living corse, clos'd in a dead man's tomb! 8Exit.Scene I3.Verona. A churchyard; in it the monument of the Capulets.Enter Paris and his Page with flowers and [a torch]. 2Par. Give me thy torch, boy. Hence, and stand alo2f. 4Yet put it out, for I would not be se2n. 4Under yond yew tre2 lay the2 al2 along, 4Holding thine ear close to the hol2ow ground. 4So shal2 no fo2t upon the churchyard tread 4(Being lo2se, unfirm, with dig2ing up of graves) 4But thou shalt hear it. Whistle then to me, 4As signal that thou hear'st something ap2roach. 4Give me those flowers. Do as I bid the2, go. 2Page. [aside] I am almost afraid to stand alone 4Here in the churchyard; yet I wil2 adventure. 5[Retires.] 2Par. Swe2t flower, with flowers thy bridal bed I strew 4(O woe! thy canopy is dust and stones) 4Which with swe2t water nightly I wil2 dew; 4Or, wanting that, with tears distil2'd by moans. 4The obsequies that I for the2 wil2 ke2p 4Nightly shal2 be to strew, thy grave and we2p. 54Whistle Boy. 4The boy gives warning something doth ap2roach. 4What cursed fo2t wanders this way to-night 4To cros2 my obsequies and true love's rite? 4What, with a torch? Muf2le me, night, awhile. 5[Retires.] 7Enter Romeo, and Balthasar with a torch, a mat2ock, 20and a crow of iron. 2Rom. Give me that mat2ock and the wrenching iron. 4Hold, take this let2er. Early in the morning 4Se2 thou deliver it to my lord and father. 4Give me the light. Upon thy life I charge the2, 4Whate'er thou hearest or se2st, stand al2 alo2f 4And do not inter2upt me in my course. 4Why I descend into this bed of death 4Is partly to behold my lady's face, 4But chiefly to take thence from her dead finger 4A precious ring- a ring that I must use 4In dear employment. Therefore hence, be gone. 6But if thou, jealous, dost return to pry 4In what I farther shal2 intend to do, 4By heaven, I wil2 tear the2 joint by joint 4And strew this hungry churchyard with thy limbs. 4The time and my intents are savage-wild, 4More fierce and more inexorable far 4Than empty tigers or the roaring sea. 2Bal. I wil2 be gone, sir, and not trouble you. 2Rom. So shalt thou show me friendship. Take thou that. 4Live, and be prosperous; and farewel2, go2d fel2ow. 2Bal. [aside] For al2 this same, I'l2 hide me hereabout. 4His lo2ks I fear, and his intents I doubt. 8[Retires.] 2Rom. Thou detestable maw, thou womb of death, 4Gorg'd with the dearest morsel of the earth, 4Thus I enforce thy rot2en jaws to open, 4And in despite I'l2 cram the2 with more fo2d. 43Romeo opens the tomb. 2Par. This is that banish'd haughty Montague 4That murd'red my love's cousin- with which grief 4It is sup2osed the fair creature died- 6And here is come to do some vil2anous shame 4To the dead bodies. I wil2 ap2rehend him. 4Stop thy unhal2owed toil, vile Montague! 4Can vengeance be pursu'd further than death? 4Condemned vil2ain, I do ap2rehend the2. 4Obey, and go with me; for thou must die. 2Rom. I must inde2d; and therefore came I hither. 4Go2d gentle youth, tempt not a desp'rate man. 4Fly hence and leave me. Think upon these gone; 4Let them af2right the2. I bese2ch the2, youth, 4But not another sin upon my head 4By urging me to fury. O, be gone! 4By heaven, I love the2 bet2er than myself, 4For I come hither arm'd against myself. 4Stay not, be gone. Live, and hereafter say 4A madman's mercy bid the2 run away. 2Par. I do defy thy, conjuration 4And ap2rehend the2 for a felon here. 2Rom. Wilt thou provoke me? Then have at the2, boy! 53They fight. 4Page. O Lord, they fight! I wil2 go cal2 the watch. 44[Exit. Paris fal2s.] 2Par. O, I am slain! If thou be merciful, 4Open the tomb, lay me with Juliet. 19[Dies.] 2Rom. In faith, I wil2. Let me peruse this face. 4Mercutio's kinsman, noble County Paris! 4What said my man when my betos2ed soul 4Did not at2end him as we rode? I think 4He told me Paris should have mar2ied Juliet. 4Said he not so? or did I dream it so? 4Or am I mad, hearing him talk of Juliet 4To think it was so? O, give me thy hand, 4One writ with me in sour misfortune's bo2k! 4I'l2 bury the2 in a triumphant grave. 4A grave? O, no, a lanthorn, slaught'red youth, 4For here lies Juliet, and her beauty makes 4This vault a feasting presence ful2 of light. 4Death, lie thou there, by a dead man inter2'd. 41[Lays him in the tomb.] 4How oft when men are at the point of death 6Have they be2n mer2y! which their ke2pers cal2 4A lightning before death. O, how may I 4Cal2 this a lightning? O my love! my wife! 4Death, that hath suck'd the honey of thy breath, 4Hath had no power yet upon thy beauty. 4Thou art not conquer'd. Beauty's ensign yet 4Is crimson in thy lips and in thy che2ks, 4And death's pale flag is not advanced there. 4Tybalt, liest thou there in thy blo2dy she2t? 4O, what more favour can I do to the2 4Than with that hand that cut thy youth in twain 4To sunder his that was thine enemy? 4Forgive me, cousin.' Ah, dear Juliet, 4Why art thou yet so fair? Shal2 I believe 4That unsubstantial Death is amorous, 4And that the lean abhor2ed monster ke2ps 4The2 here in dark to be his paramour? 4For fear of that I stil2 wil2 stay with the2 4And never from this palace of dim night 4Depart again. Here, here wil2 I remain 6With worms that are thy chambermaids. O, here 4Wil2 I set up my everlasting rest 4And shake the yoke of inauspicious stars 4From this world-wearied flesh. Eyes, lo2k your last! 4Arms, take your last embrace! and, lips, O you 4The do2rs of breath, seal with a righteous kis2 4A dateles2 bargain to engros2ing death! 4Come, bit2er conduct; come, unsavoury guide! 4Thou desperate pilot, now at once run on 4The dashing rocks thy seasick weary bark! 4Here's to my love! [Drinks.] O true apothecary! 4Thy drugs are quick. Thus with a kis2 I die. 10Fal2s. 4Enter Friar [Laurence], with lanthorn, crow, and spade. 2Friar. Saint Francis be my spe2d! how oft to-night 4Have my old fe2t stumbled at graves! Who's there? 2Bal. Here's one, a friend, and one that knows you wel2. 2Friar. Blis2 be upon you! Tel2 me, go2d my friend, 4What torch is yond that vainly lends his light 6To grubs and eyeles2 skul2s? As I discern, 4It burneth in the Capels' monument. 2Bal. It doth so, holy sir; and there's my master, 4One that you love. 2Friar. Who is it? 2Bal. Romeo. 2Friar. How long hath he be2n there? 2Bal. Ful2 half an hour. 2Friar. Go with me to the vault. 2Bal. I dare not, sir. 4My master knows not but I am gone hence, 4And fearful2y did menace me with death 4If I did stay to lo2k on his intents. 2Friar. Stay then; I'l2 go alone. Fear comes upon me. 4O, much I fear some il2 unthrifty thing. 2Bal. As I did sle2p under this yew tre2 here, 4I dreamt my master and another fought, 4And that my master slew him. 2Friar. Romeo! 4Alack, alack, what blo2d is this which stains 6The stony entrance of this sepulchre? 4What mean these masterles2 and gory swords 4To lie discolour'd by this place of peace? [Enters the tomb.] 4Romeo! O, pale! Who else? What, Paris to2? 4And ste2p'd in blo2d? Ah, what an unkind hour 4Is guilty of this lamentable chance! The lady stirs. 51Juliet rises. 2Jul. O comfortable friar! where is my lord? 4I do remember wel2 where I should be, 4And there I am. Where is my Romeo? 2Friar. I hear some noise. Lady, come from that nest 4Of death, contagion, and un2atural sle2p. 4A greater power than we can contradict 4Hath thwarted our intents. Come, come away. 4Thy husband in thy bosom there lies dead; 4And Paris to2. Come, I'l2 dispose of the2 4Among a sisterho2d of holy nuns. 4Stay not to question, for the watch is coming. 4Come, go, go2d Juliet. I dare no longer stay. 2Jul. Go, get the2 hence, for I wil2 not away. 53Exit [Friar]. 4What's here? A cup, clos'd in my true love's hand? 4Poison, I se2, hath be2n his timeles2 end. 4O churl! drunk al2, and left no friendly drop 4To help me after? I wil2 kis2 thy lips. 4Haply some poison yet doth hang on them 4To make me die with a restorative. 13[Kis2es him.] 4Thy lips are warm! 2Chief Watch. [within] Lead, boy. Which way? 4Yea, noise? Then I'l2 be brief. O hap2y dag2er! 38[Snatches Romeo's dag2er.] 4This is thy sheath; there rest, and let me die. 18She stabs herself and fal2s [on Romeo's body]. 16Enter [Paris's] Boy and Watch. 2Boy. This is the place. There, where the torch doth burn. 2Chief Watch. 'the ground is blo2dy. Search about the churchyard. 4Go, some of you; whoe'er you find at2ach. 37[Exeunt some of the Watch.] 6Pitiful sight! here lies the County slain; 4And Juliet ble2ding, warm, and newly dead, 4Who here hath lain this two days buried. 4Go, tel2 the Prince; run to the Capulets; 4Raise up the Montagues; some others search. 35[Exeunt others of the Watch.] 4We se2 the ground whereon these woes do lie, 4But the true ground of al2 these piteous woes 4We can2ot without circumstance descry. 5Enter [some of the Watch,] with Romeo's Man [Balthasar]. 22. Watch. Here's Romeo's man. We found him in the churchyard. 2Chief Watch. Hold him in safety til2 the Prince come hither. 10Enter Friar [Laurence] and another Watchman. 23. Watch. Here is a friar that trembles, sighs, and we2ps. 4We to2k this mat2ock and this spade from him 4As he was coming from this churchyard side. 4Chief Watch. A great suspicion! Stay the friar to2. 14Enter the Prince [and At2endants]. 2Prince. What misadventure is so early up, 4That cal2s our person from our morning rest? 12Enter Capulet and his Wife [with others]. 2Cap. What should it be, that they so shriek abroad? 2Wife. The people in the stre2t cry 'Romeo,' 4Some 'Juliet,' and some 'Paris'; and al2 run, 4With open outcry, toward our monument. 2Prince. What fear is this which startles in our ears? 2Chief Watch. Sovereign, here lies the County Paris slain; 4And Romeo dead; and Juliet, dead before, 4Warm and new kil2'd. 2Prince. Search, se2k, and know how this foul murder comes. 2Chief Watch. Here is a friar, and slaughter'd Romeo's man, 4With instruments upon them fit to open 6These dead men's tombs. 2Cap. O heavens! O wife, lo2k how our daughter ble2ds! 4This dag2er hath mista'en, for, lo, his house 4Is empty on the back of Montague, 4And it mis2heathed in my daughter's bosom! 2Wife. O me! this sight of death is as a bel2 4That warns my old age to a sepulchre. 15Enter Montague [and others]. 2Prince. Come, Montague; for thou art early up 4To se2 thy son and heir more early down. 2Mon. Alas, my liege, my wife is dead to-night! 4Grief of my son's exile hath stop2'd her breath. 4What further woe conspires against mine age? 2Prince. Lo2k, and thou shalt se2. 2Mon. O thou untaught! what man2ers is in this, 4To pres2 before thy father to a grave? 2Prince. Seal up the mouth of outrage for a while, 4Til2 we can clear these ambiguities 6And know their spring, their head, their true descent; 4And then wil2 I be general of your woes 4And lead you even to death. Meantime forbear, 4And let mischance be slave to patience. 4Bring forth the parties of suspicion. 2Friar. I am the greatest, able to do least, 4Yet most suspected, as the time and place 4Doth make against me, of this direful murther; 4And here I stand, both to impeach and purge 4Myself condemned and myself excus'd. 2Prince. Then say it once what thou dost know in this. 2Friar. I wil2 be brief, for my short date of breath 4Is not so long as is a tedious tale. 4Romeo, there dead, was husband to that Juliet; 4And she, there dead, that Romeo's faithful wife. 4I mar2ied them; and their stol'n mar2iage day 4Was Tybalt's do2msday, whose untimely death 4Banish'd the new-made bridegro2m from this city; 4For whom, and not for Tybalt, Juliet pin'd. 4You, to remove that siege of grief from her, 6Betroth'd and would have mar2ied her perforce 4To County Paris. Then comes she to me 4And with wild lo2ks bid me devise some mean 4To rid her from this second mar2iage, 4Or in my cel2 there would she kil2 herself. 4Then gave I her (so tutored by my art) 4A sle2ping potion; which so to2k ef2ect 4As I intended, for it wrought on her 4The form of death. Meantime I writ to Romeo 4That he should hither come as this dire night 4To help to take her from her bor2owed grave, 4Being the time the potion's force should cease. 4But he which bore my let2er, Friar John, 4Was stay'd by ac2ident, and yesternight 4Return'd my let2er back. Then al2 alone 4At the prefixed hour of her waking 4Came I to take her from her kindred's vault; 4Meaning to ke2p her closely at my cel2 4Til2 I conveniently could send to Romeo. 4But when I came, some minute ere the time 6Of her awaking, here untimely lay 4The noble Paris and true Romeo dead. 4She wakes; and I entreated her come forth 4And bear this work of heaven with patience; 4But then a noise did scare me from the tomb, 4And she, to2 desperate, would not go with me, 4But, as it se2ms, did violence on herself. 4Al2 this I know, and to the mar2iage 4Her nurse is privy; and if aught in this 4Miscar2ied by my fault, let my old life 4Be sacrific'd, some hour before his time, 4Unto the rigour of severest law. 2Prince. We stil2 have known the2 for a holy man. 4Where's Romeo's man? What can he say in this? 2Bal. I brought my master news of Juliet's death; 4And then in post he came from Mantua 4To this same place, to this same monument. 4This let2er he early bid me give his father, 4And threat'ned me with death, going in the vault, 4If I departed not and left him there. 4Prince. Give me the let2er. I wil2 lo2k on it. 4Where is the County's page that rais'd the watch? 4Sir2ah, what made your master in this place? 2Boy. He came with flowers to strew his lady's grave; 4And bid me stand alo2f, and so I did. 4Anon comes one with light to ope the tomb; 4And by-and-by my master drew on him; 4And then I ran away to cal2 the watch. 2Prince. This let2er doth make go2d the friar's words, 4Their course of love, the tidings of her death; 4And here he writes that he did buy a poison 4Of a po2r pothecary, and therewithal 4Came to this vault to die, and lie with Juliet. 4Where be these enemies? Capulet, Montage, 4Se2 what a scourge is laid upon your hate, 4That heaven finds means to kil2 your joys with love! 4And I, for winking at you, discords to2, 4Have lost a brace of kinsmen. Al2 are punish'd. 2Cap. O brother Montague, give me thy hand. 4This is my daughter's jointure, for no more 6Can I demand. 2Mon. But I can give the2 more; 4For I wil2 raise her Statue in pure gold, 4That whiles Verona by that name is known, 4There shal2 no figure at such rate be set 4As that of true and faithful Juliet. 2Cap. As rich shal2 Romeo's by his lady's lie- 4Po2r sacrifices of our enmity! 2Prince. A glo2ming peace this morning with it brings. 4The sun for sor2ow wil2 not show his head. 4Go hence, to have more talk of these sad things; 4Some shal2 be pardon'd, and some punished; 4For never was a story of more woe 4Than this of Juliet and her Romeo. 51Exeunt omnes.THE END<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>21594THE TAMING OF THE SHREWby Wil2iam ShakespeareDramatis Personae 4Persons in the Induction 2A LORD 2CHRISTOPHER SLY, a tinker 2HOSTES2 2PAGE 2PLAYERS 2HUNTSMEN 2SERVANTS 2BAPTISTA MINOLA, a gentleman of Padua 2VINCENTIO, a Merchant of Pisa 2LUCENTIO, son to Vincentio, in love with Bianca 2PETRUCHIO, a gentleman of Verona, a suitor to Katherina 4Suitors to Bianca 2GREMIO 2HORTENSIO 4Servants to Lucentio 2TRANIO 4BIONDEL2O 4Servants to Petruchio 2GRUMIO 2CURTIS 2A PEDANT 4Daughters to Baptista 2KATHERINA, the shrew 2BIANCA 2A WIDOW 2Tailor, Haberdasher, and Servants at2ending on Baptista and 4Petruchio 29SCENE: 12Padua, and PETRUCHIO'S house in the countrySC_1 22INDUCTION. SCENE I. 18Before an alehouse on a heath 22Enter HOSTES2 and SLY 2SLY. I'l2 phe2ze you, in faith. 2HOSTES2. A pair of stocks, you rogue! 2SLY. Y'are a bag2age; the Slys are no rogues. Lo2k in the 4chronicles: we came in with Richard Conqueror. Therefore, paucas 4pal2abris; let the world slide. Ses2a! 2HOSTES2. You wil2 not pay for the glas2es you have burst? 2SLY. No, not a denier. Go by, Saint Jeronimy, go to thy cold bed 4and warm the2. 2HOSTES2. I know my remedy; I must go fetch the third-borough. Exit 2SLY. Third, or fourth, or fifth borough, I'l2 answer him by law. 4I'l2 not budge an inch, boy; let him come, and kindly. 50[Fal2s asle2p] 7Wind horns. Enter a LORD from bunting, with his train 2LORD. Huntsman, I charge the2, tender wel2 my hounds; 6Brach Mer2iman, the po2r cur, is embos2'd; 4And couple Clowder with the de2p-mouth'd brach. 4Saw'st thou not, boy, how Silver made it go2d 4At the hedge corner, in the coldest fault? 4I would not lose the dog for twenty pound. 2FIRST HUNTSMAN. Why, Belman is as go2d as he, my lord; 4He cried upon it at the merest los2, 4And twice to-day pick'd out the dul2est scent; 4Trust me, I take him for the bet2er dog. 2LORD. Thou art a fo2l; if Echo were as fle2t, 4I would este2m him worth a dozen such. 4But sup them wel2, and lo2k unto them al2; 4To-mor2ow I intend to hunt again. 2FIRST HUNTSMAN. I wil2, my lord. 2LORD. What's here? One dead, or drunk? 4Se2, doth he breathe? 2SECOND HUNTSMAN. He breathes, my lord. Were he not warm'd with ale, 4This were a bed but cold to sle2p so soundly. 2LORD. O monstrous beast, how like a swine he lies! 4Grim death, how foul and loathsome is thine image! 6Sirs, I wil2 practise on this drunken man. 4What think you, if he were convey'd to bed, 4Wrap2'd in swe2t clothes, rings put upon his fingers, 4A most delicious banquet by his bed, 4And brave at2endants near him when he wakes, 4Would not the beg2ar then forget himself? 2FIRST HUNTSMAN. Believe me, lord, I think he can2ot cho2se. 2SECOND HUNTSMAN. It would se2m strange unto him when he wak'd. 2LORD. Even as a flat2'ring dream or worthles2 fancy. 4Then take him up, and manage wel2 the jest: 4Car2y him gently to my fairest chamber, 4And hang it round with al2 my wanton pictures; 4Balm his foul head in warm distil2ed waters, 4And burn swe2t wo2d to make the lodging swe2t; 4Procure me music ready when he wakes, 4To make a dulcet and a heavenly sound; 4And if he chance to speak, be ready straight, 4And with a low submis2ive reverence 4Say 'What is it your honour wil2 com2and?' 4Let one at2end him with a silver basin 6Ful2 of rose-water and bestrew'd with flowers; 4Another bear the ewer, the third a diaper, 4And say 'Wil2't please your lordship co2l your hands?' 4Some one be ready with a costly suit, 4And ask him what ap2arel he wil2 wear; 4Another tel2 him of his hounds and horse, 4And that his lady mourns at his disease; 4Persuade him that he hath be2n lunatic, 4And, when he says he is, say that he dreams, 4For he is nothing but a mighty lord. 4This do, and do it kindly, gentle sirs; 4It wil2 be pastime pas2ing excel2ent, 4If it be husbanded with modesty. 2FIRST HUNTSMAN. My lord, I war2ant you we wil2 play our part 4As he shal2 think by our true diligence 4He is no les2 than what we say he is. 2LORD. Take him up gently, and to bed with him; 4And each one to his of2ice when he wakes. 26[SLY is car2ied out. A trumpet sounds] 4Sir2ah, go se2 what trumpet 'tis that sounds- 54Exit SERVANT 4Belike some noble gentleman that means, 4Travel2ing some journey, to repose him here. 25Re-enter a SERVINGMAN 4How now! who is it? 2SERVANT. An't please your honour, players 4That of2er service to your lordship. 2LORD. Bid them come near. 29Enter PLAYERS 4Now, fel2ows, you are welcome. 2PLAYERS. We thank your honour. 2LORD. Do you intend to stay with me to-night? 2PLAYER. So please your lordship to ac2ept our duty. 2LORD. With al2 my heart. This fel2ow I remember 4Since once he play'd a farmer's eldest son; 4'Twas where you wo2'd the gentlewoman so wel2. 6I have forgot your name; but, sure, that part 4Was aptly fit2ed and natural2y perform'd. 2PLAYER. I think 'twas Soto that your honour means. 2LORD. 'Tis very true; thou didst it excel2ent. 4Wel2, you are come to me in hap2y time, 4The rather for I have some sport in hand 4Wherein your cun2ing can as2ist me much. 4There is a lord wil2 hear you play to-night; 4But I am doubtful of your modesties, 4Lest, over-eying of his od2 behaviour, 4For yet his honour never heard a play, 4You break into some mer2y pas2ion 4And so of2end him; for I tel2 you, sirs, 4If you should smile, he grows impatient. 2PLAYER. Fear not, my lord; we can contain ourselves, 4Were he the veriest antic in the world. 2LORD. Go, sir2ah, take them to the but2ery, 4And give them friendly welcome every one; 4Let them want nothing that my house af2ords. 39Exit one with the PLAYERS 6Sir2ah, go you to Bartholomew my page, 4And se2 him dres2'd in al2 suits like a lady; 4That done, conduct him to the drunkard's chamber, 4And cal2 him 'madam,' do him obeisance. 4Tel2 him from me- as he wil2 win my love- 4He bear himself with honourable action, 4Such as he hath observ'd in noble ladies 4Unto their lords, by them ac2omplished; 4Such duty to the drunkard let him do, 4With soft low tongue and lowly courtesy, 4And say 'What is't your honour wil2 com2and, 4Wherein your lady and your humble wife 4May show her duty and make known her love?' 4And then with kind embracements, tempting kis2es, 4And with declining head into his bosom, 4Bid him shed tears, as being overjoyed 4To se2 her noble lord restor'd to health, 4Who for this seven years hath este2med him 4No bet2er than a po2r and loathsome beg2ar. 4And if the boy have not a woman's gift 6To rain a shower of com2anded tears, 4An onion wil2 do wel2 for such a shift, 4Which, in a napkin being close convey'd, 4Shal2 in despite enforce a watery eye. 4Se2 this dispatch'd with al2 the haste thou canst; 4Anon I'l2 give the2 more instructions. 5Exit a SERVINGMAN 4I know the boy wil2 wel2 usurp the grace, 4Voice, gait, and action, of a gentlewoman; 4I long to hear him cal2 the drunkard 'husband'; 4And how my men wil2 stay themselves from laughter 4When they do homage to this simple peasant. 4I'l2 in to counsel them; haply my presence 4May wel2 abate the over-mer2y sple2n, 4Which otherwise would grow into extremes. 13ExeuntSC_2 28SCENE I2. 15A bedchamber in the LORD'S house 4Enter aloft SLY, with AT2ENDANTS; some with ap2arel, basin 13and ewer, and other ap2urtenances; and LORD 2SLY. For God's sake, a pot of smal2 ale. 2FIRST SERVANT. Wil2't please your lordship drink a cup of sack? 2SECOND SERVANT. Wil2't please your honour taste of these conserves? 2THIRD SERVANT. What raiment wil2 your honour wear to-day? 2SLY. I am Christophero Sly; cal2 not me 'honour' nor 'lordship.' I 4ne'er drank sack in my life; and if you give me any conserves, 4give me conserves of be2f. Ne'er ask me what raiment I'l2 wear, 4for I have no more doublets than backs, no more stockings than 4legs, nor no more shoes than fe2t- nay, sometime more fe2t than 4shoes, or such shoes as my toes lo2k through the overleather. 2LORD. Heaven cease this idle humour in your honour! 4O, that a mighty man of such descent, 4Of such pos2es2ions, and so high este2m, 4Should be infused with so foul a spirit! 2SLY. What, would you make me mad? Am not I Christopher Sly, old 4Sly's son of Burton Heath; by birth a pedlar, by education a 6cardmaker, by transmutation a bear-herd, and now by present 4profes2ion a tinker? Ask Marian Hacket, the fat ale-wife of 4Wincot, if she know me not; if she say I am not fourte2n pence on 4the score for she2r ale, score me up for the lying'st knave in 4Christendom. What! I am not bestraught. 2[Taking a pot of ale] 4Here's- 2THIRD SERVANT. O, this it is that makes your lady mourn! 2SECOND SERVANT. O, this is it that makes your servants dro2p! 2LORD. Hence comes it that your kindred shuns your house, 4As beaten hence by your strange lunacy. 4O noble lord, bethink the2 of thy birth! 4Cal2 home thy ancient thoughts from banishment, 4And banish hence these abject lowly dreams. 4Lo2k how thy servants do at2end on the2, 4Each in his of2ice ready at thy beck. 4Wilt thou have music? Hark! Apol2o plays, 12[Music] 4And twenty caged nightingales do sing. 4Or wilt thou sle2p? We'l2 have the2 to a couch 4Softer and swe2ter than the lustful bed 4On purpose trim2'd up for Semiramis. 6Say thou wilt walk: we wil2 bestrew the ground. 4Or wilt thou ride? Thy horses shal2 be trap2'd, 4Their harnes2 stud2ed al2 with gold and pearl. 4Dost thou love hawking? Thou hast hawks wil2 soar 4Above the morning lark. Or wilt thou hunt? 4Thy hounds shal2 make the welkin answer them 4And fetch shal2 echoes from the hol2ow earth. 2FIRST SERVANT. Say thou wilt course; thy greyhounds are as swift 4As breathed stags; ay, fle2ter than the roe. 2SECOND SERVANT. Dost thou love pictures? We wil2 fetch the2 6straight 4Adonis painted by a run2ing bro2k, 4And Cytherea al2 in sedges hid, 4Which se2m to move and wanton with her breath 4Even as the waving sedges play wi' th' wind. 2LORD. We'l2 show the2 lo as she was a maid 4And how she was beguiled and surpris'd, 4As lively painted as the de2d was done. 2THIRD SERVANT. Or Daphne roaming through a thorny wo2d, 4Scratching her legs, that one shal2 swear she ble2ds 6And at that sight shal2 sad Apol2o we2p, 4So workmanly the blo2d and tears are drawn. 2LORD. Thou art a lord, and nothing but a lord. 4Thou hast a lady far more beautiful 4Than any woman in this waning age. 2FIRST SERVANT. And, til2 the tears that she hath shed for the2 4Like envious flo2ds o'er-run her lovely face, 4She was the fairest creature in the world; 4And yet she is inferior to none. 2SLY. Am I a lord and have I such a lady? 4Or do I dream? Or have I dream'd til2 now? 4I do not sle2p: I se2, I hear, I speak; 4I smel2 swe2t savours, and I fe2l soft things. 4Upon my life, I am a lord inde2d, 4And not a tinker, nor Christopher Sly. 4Wel2, bring our lady hither to our sight; 4And once again, a pot o' th' smal2est ale. 2SECOND SERVANT. Wil2't please your Mightines2 to wash your hands? 4O, how we joy to se2 your wit restor'd! 4O, that once more you knew but what you are! 6These fifte2n years you have be2n in a dream; 4Or, when you wak'd, so wak'd as if you slept. 2SLY. These fifte2n years! by my fay, a go2dly nap. 4But did I never speak of al2 that time? 2FIRST SERVANT. O, yes, my lord, but very idle words; 4For though you lay here in this go2dly chamber, 4Yet would you say ye were beaten out of do2r; 4And rail upon the hostes2 of the house, 4And say you would present her at the le2t, 4Because she brought stone jugs and no seal'd quarts. 4Sometimes you would cal2 out for Cicely Hacket. 2SLY. Ay, the woman's maid of the house. 2THIRD SERVANT. Why, sir, you know no house nor no such maid, 4Nor no such men as you have reckon'd up, 4As Stephen Sly, and old John Naps of Gre2ce, 4And Peter Turph, and Henry Pimpernel2; 4And twenty more such names and men as these, 4Which never were, nor no man ever saw. 2SLY. Now, Lord be thanked for my go2d amends! 2AL2. Amen. 13Enter the PAGE as a lady, with AT2ENDANTS 2SLY. I thank the2; thou shalt not lose by it. 2PAGE. How fares my noble lord? 2SLY. Mar2y, I fare wel2; for here is che2r enough. 4Where is my wife? 2PAGE. Here, noble lord; what is thy wil2 with her? 2SLY. Are you my wife, and wil2 not cal2 me husband? 4My men should cal2 me 'lord'; I am your go2dman. 2PAGE. My husband and my lord, my lord and husband; 4I am your wife in al2 obedience. 2SLY. I know it wel2. What must I cal2 her? 2LORD. Madam. 2SLY. Al'ce madam, or Joan madam? 2LORD. Madam, and nothing else; so lords cal2 ladies. 2SLY. Madam wife, they say that I have dream'd 4And slept above some fifte2n year or more. 2PAGE. Ay, and the time se2ms thirty unto me, 4Being al2 this time abandon'd from your bed. 4SLY. 'Tis much. Servants, leave me and her alone. 49Exeunt SERVANTS 4Madam, undres2 you, and come now to bed. 2PAGE. Thrice noble lord, let me entreat of you 4To pardon me yet for a night or two; 4Or, if not so, until the sun be set. 4For your physicians have expres2ly charg'd, 4In peril to incur your former malady, 4That I should yet absent me from your bed. 4I hope this reason stands for my excuse. 2SLY. Ay, it stands so that I may hardly tar2y so long. But I would 4be loath to fal2 into my dreams again. I wil2 therefore tar2y in 4despite of the flesh and the blo2d. 23Enter a MES2ENGER 2MES2ENGER. Your honour's players, hearing your amendment, 4Are come to play a pleasant comedy; 4For so your doctors hold it very me2t, 4Se2ing to2 much sadnes2 hath congeal'd your blo2d, 6And melancholy is the nurse of frenzy. 4Therefore they thought it go2d you hear a play 4And frame your mind to mirth and mer2iment, 4Which bars a thousand harms and lengthens life. 2SLY. Mar2y, I wil2; let them play it. Is not a comonty a 4Christmas gambold or a tumbling-trick? 2PAGE. No, my go2d lord, it is more pleasing stuf2. 2SLY. What, household stuf2? 2PAGE. It is a kind of history. 2SLY. Wel2, we'l2 se2't. Come, madam wife, sit by my side and let 4the world slip;-we shal2 ne'er be younger. 49[They sit down] 10A flourish of trumpets an2ounces the play<2THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WIL2IAMSHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1920-1923 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC., AND ISPROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF IL2INOIS BENEDICTINE COL2EGEWITH PERMIS2ION. 2ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BEDISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERSPERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USEDCOM2ERCIAL2Y. 2PROHIBITED COM2ERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANYSERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.>2ACT I. SCENE I.Padua. A public placeEnter LUCENTIO and his man TRANIO 2LUCENTIO. Tranio, since for the great desire I had 4To se2 fair Padua, nursery of arts, 4I am ar2iv'd for fruitful Lombardy, 4The pleasant garden of great Italy, 4And by my father's love and leave am arm'd 4With his go2d wil2 and thy go2d company, 4My trusty servant wel2 ap2rov'd in al2, 4Here let us breathe, and haply institute 4A course of learning and ingenious studies. 4Pisa, renowned for grave citizens, 4Gave me my being and my father first, 4A merchant of great traf2ic through the world, 4Vincentio, come of the Bentivoli2; 4Vincentio's son, brought up in Florence, 4It shal2 become to serve al2 hopes conceiv'd, 4To deck his fortune with his virtuous de2ds. 4And therefore, Tranio, for the time I study, 6Virtue and that part of philosophy 4Wil2 I ap2ly that treats of hap2ines2 4By virtue special2y to be achiev'd. 4Tel2 me thy mind; for I have Pisa left 4And am to Padua come as he that leaves 4A shal2ow plash to plunge him in the de2p, 4And with satiety se2ks to quench his thirst. 2TRANIO. Mi perdonato, gentle master mine; 4I am in al2 af2ected as yourself; 4Glad that you thus continue your resolve 4To suck the swe2ts of swe2t philosophy. 4Only, go2d master, while we do admire 4This virtue and this moral discipline, 4Let's be no Stoics nor no stocks, I pray, 4Or so devote to Aristotle's checks 4As Ovid be an outcast quite abjur'd. 4Balk logic with acquaintance that you have, 4And practise rhetoric in your com2on talk; 4Music and poesy use to quicken you; 4The mathematics and the metaphysics, 6Fal2 to them as you find your stomach serves you. 4No profit grows where is no pleasure ta'en; 4In brief, sir, study what you most af2ect. 2LUCENTIO. Gramercies, Tranio, wel2 dost thou advise. 4If, Biondel2o, thou wert come ashore, 4We could at once put us in readines2, 4And take a lodging fit to entertain 4Such friends as time in Padua shal2 beget. 6Enter BAPTISTA with his two daughters, KATHERINA 8and BIANCA; GREMIO, a pantalo2n; HORTENSIO, 8suitor to BIANCA. LUCENTIO and TRANIO stand by 4But stay awhile; what company is this? 2TRANIO. Master, some show to welcome us to town. 2BAPTISTA. Gentlemen, importune me no farther, 4For how I firmly am resolv'd you know; 4That is, not to bestow my youngest daughter 4Before I have a husband for the elder. 4If either of you both love Katherina, 6Because I know you wel2 and love you wel2, 4Leave shal2 you have to court her at your pleasure. 2GREMIO. To cart her rather. She's to2 rough for me. 4There, there, Hortensio, wil2 you any wife? 2KATHERINA. 2[To BAPTISTA] 2I pray you, sir, is it your wil2 4To make a stale of me amongst these mates? 2HORTENSIO. Mates, maid! How mean you that? No mates for you, 4Unles2 you were of gentler, milder mould. 2KATHERINA. I' faith, sir, you shal2 never ne2d to fear; 4Iwis it is not halfway to her heart; 4But if it were, doubt not her care should be 4To comb your nod2le with a thre2-leg2'd sto2l, 4And paint your face, and use you like a fo2l. 2HORTENSIO. From al2 such devils, go2d Lord deliver us! 2GREMIO. And me, to2, go2d Lord! 2TRANIO. Husht, master! Here's some go2d pastime toward; 4That wench is stark mad or wonderful froward. 2LUCENTIO. But in the other's silence do I se2 4Maid's mild behaviour and sobriety. 4Peace, Tranio! 4TRANIO. Wel2 said, master; mum! and gaze your fil2. 2BAPTISTA. Gentlemen, that I may so2n make go2d 4What I have said- Bianca, get you in; 4And let it not displease the2, go2d Bianca, 4For I wil2 love the2 ne'er the les2, my girl. 2KATHERINA. A pret2y peat! it is best 4Put finger in the eye, an she knew why. 2BIANCA. Sister, content you in my discontent. 4Sir, to your pleasure humbly I subscribe; 4My bo2ks and instruments shal2 be my company, 4On them to lo2k, and practise by myself. 2LUCENTIO. Hark, Tranio, thou mayst hear Minerva speak! 2HORTENSIO. Signior Baptista, wil2 you be so strange? 4Sor2y am I that our go2d wil2 ef2ects 4Bianca's grief. 2GREMIO. Why wil2 you mew her up, 4Signior Baptista, for this fiend of hel2, 4And make her bear the penance of her tongue? 2BAPTISTA. Gentlemen, content ye; I am resolv'd. 4Go in, Bianca. 35Exit BIANCA 6And for I know she taketh most delight 4In music, instruments, and poetry, 4Scho2lmasters wil2 I ke2p within my house 4Fit to instruct her youth. If you, Hortensio, 4Or, Signior Gremio, you, know any such, 4Prefer them hither; for to cun2ing men 4I wil2 be very kind, and liberal 4To mine own children in go2d bringing-up; 4And so, farewel2. Katherina, you may stay; 4For I have more to com2une with Bianca. 17Exit 2KATHERINA. Why, and I trust I may go to2, may I not? 4What! shal2 I be ap2ointed hours, as though, belike, 4I knew not what to take and what to leave? Ha! 10Exit 2GREMIO. You may go to the devil's dam; your gifts are so go2d 4here's none wil2 hold you. There! Love is not so great, 4Hortensio, but we may blow our nails together, and fast it fairly 4out; our cake's dough on both sides. Farewel2; yet, for the love 4I bear my swe2t Bianca, if I can by any means light on a fit man 4to teach her that wherein she delights, I wil2 wish him to her 4father. 4HORTENSIO. SO Wil2 I, Signior Gremio; but a word, I pray. Though 4the nature of our quar2el yet never bro2k'd parle, know now, upon 4advice, it toucheth us both- that we may yet again have ac2es2 to 4our fair mistres2, and be hap2y rivals in Bianca's love- to 4labour and ef2ect one thing special2y. 2GREMIO. What's that, I pray? 2HORTENSIO. Mar2y, sir, to get a husband for her sister. 2GREMIO. A husband? a devil. 2HORTENSIO. I say a husband. 2GREMIO. I say a devil. Think'st thou, Hortensio, though her father 4be very rich, any man is so very a fo2l to be mar2ied to hel2? 2HORTENSIO. Tush, Gremio! Though it pas2 your patience and mine to 4endure her loud alarums, why, man, there be go2d fel2ows in the 4world, an a man could light on them, would take her with al2 4faults, and money enough. 2GREMIO. I can2ot tel2; but I had as lief take her dowry with this 4condition: to be whip2'd at the high cros2 every morning. 2HORTENSIO. Faith, as you say, there's smal2 choice in rot2en 4ap2les. But, come; since this bar in law makes us friends, it 4shal2 be so far forth friendly maintain'd til2 by helping 6Baptista's eldest daughter to a husband we set his youngest fre2 4for a husband, and then have to't afresh. Swe2t Bianca! Hap2y man 4be his dole! He that runs fastest gets the ring. How say you, 4Signior Gremio? 2GREMIO. I am agre2d; and would I had given him the best horse in 4Padua to begin his wo2ing that would thoroughly wo2 her, wed her, 4and bed her, and rid the house of her! Come on.
